teɪbəl ə kɑntɛns taɪɾəl kɑpiɹaɪt dɛɾəkeɪʃən kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: snoʊ wʌn livɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət tu teɪkən θɹi kʌstəmz fɔɹ ɔfɝz faɪv flæɡz sɪks ðə sɛn ə mædnəs sɛvən ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn eɪt si foʊk ən kɪn naɪn eɪ kʌp ə ti tɛn eɪ plæn səksidz ɪlɛvən aɪdiəz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns twɛlv eɪ lɪli ɪn wɪntɝ θɝtin wʌndɝfəl nuz fɔɹtin wʌɾ ə veɪl haɪdz fɪftin ɪn niɾ ʌv ə bɛlfndɝ sɪkstin ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝ sɛvəntin pɪŋk ɹɪbənz eɪtin ən ɔfɝ naɪntin θɹi wɪmən twɛnti kwɛstʃənz ə tʃɹizən twɛntiwʌn eɪ mæɾɝ ə pɹɑpɝɾi twɛntiɾu aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ twɛntiθɹi tə luz ðə sʌn twɛntifɔɹ əmʌŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz twɛntifaɪv bɑnz twɛntisɪks ɛkspɛkteɪʃən twɛntisɛvən tə sɝpɹaɪz kwinz ən kɪŋz twɛntieɪt nuz ɪn ə klɔθ sæk twɛntinaɪn ənʌðɝ plæn θɝɾi koʊld, fæt ɹeɪndʒɹɑps θɝɾiwʌn wʌt ði æɛlfɪn sɛd θɝɾitu eɪ pɔɹʃən ʌv wɪzdəm θɝɾiθɹi blu kɑɹp stʃɹit θɝɾifɔɹ ðə hʌmɪŋbɝdz sikɹət θɝɾifaɪv wɪð ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl ɡlɔsɝi əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ ðɪs ɪz ʌnkɝɛktɪd pɹi-ɹilis.

kɹɔsɹoʊdz ə twaɪlaɪt bʊk tɛn ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən ən ɪt ʃæl kʌm tə pæs, ɪn ðə deɪz wən ðə dɑɹk hʌn ɹaɪdz, wən ðə ɹaɪt hæn fɔltɝz ən ðə lɛf hæn stʃɹeɪz, ðət mænkaɪnd ʃæl kʌm tə ðə kɹɔsɹoʊdz ə twaɪlaɪɾ ən ɔl ðəɾ ɪz, ɔl ðət wɑz, ən ɔl ðət wɪl bi ʃæl bæləns ɑn ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə sɔɹd, waɪl ðə wɪnz ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɡɹoʊ.

CROSSROADS OF TWILIGHT Book Ten of The Wheel of Time ROBERT JORDAN And it shall come to pass, in the days when the Dark Hunt rides, when the right hand falters and the left hand strays, that mankind shall come to the Crossroads of Twilight and all that is, all that was, and all that will be shall balance on the point of a sword, while the winds of the Shadow grow.

- fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən tʃɹænzleɪʃən bɪliv dʌn baɪ dʒaɪn tʃɛɝɪn, noʊn əz dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, ʃɔɹtli bɪfɔɹ ɪz dɪsəpɪɹəns pɹoʊlɑɡ ɡlɪmɝz ə ðə pæɾɝn ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi heɪɾəd weɪɾɪŋ, ðoʊ hi wɛl nu ɪt wɑz ðə lɑɹdʒəs pɑɹɾ ə biɪŋ ə soʊlʒɝ.

- From The Prophecies of the Dragon translation believed done by Jain Charin, known as Jain Farstrider, shortly before his disappearance Prologue Glimmers of the Pattern Rodel Ituralde hated waiting, though he well knew it was the largest part of being a soldier.

weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə nɛks bæɾəl, fəɹ ði ɛnəmi tə muv, tə meɪk ə mɪsteɪk. hi wɑtʃt ðə wɪntɝ fɔɹəst ən wɑz əz stɪl əz ðə tʃɹiz. ðə sʌn stʊd hæfweɪ tə ɪts pik ən ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ. hɪz bɹɛθ mɪstɪd waɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs, fɹɔstɪŋ ɪz nitli tʃɹɪmd mʌstæʃ ən ðə blæk fɑks-fɝ laɪnɪŋ ɪz hʊd. hi wɑz ɡlæd ðəɾ ɪz hɛlmət hʌŋ əɾ ɪz pɑməl. hɪz bɹɛstpleɪt hɛl ðə koʊld ən ɹeɪɾieɪtəd ɪt θɹu hɪz koʊɾ ən ɔl ðə leɪɝz ʌv wʊl, sɪlk ən lɪnən bɪniθ. ivən dɑɹts sæɾəl fɛl koʊld, əz ðoʊ ðə waɪt ɡɛldɪŋ wɝ meɪɾ ə fɹoʊzən mɪlk. ðə hɛlmət wʊɾə æɾəld ɪz bɹeɪn.

Waiting for the next battle, for the enemy to move, to make a mistake. He watched the winter forest and was as still as the trees. The sun stood halfway to its peak and gave no warmth. His breath misted white in front of his face, frosting his neatly trimmed mustache and the black fox-fur lining his hood. He was glad that his helmet hung at his pommel. His breastplate held the cold and radiated it through his coat and all the layers of wool, silk and linen beneath. Even Dart's saddle felt cold, as though the white gelding were made of frozen milk. The helmet would have addled his brain.

wɪntɝ hæd kʌm leɪt tə ɑɹæd dumən vɛɹi leɪt, bʌt wɪð ə vɛnʒəns. fɹəm sʌmɝ hit ðət lɪŋɡɝɾ ənnətʃɝəli ɪndə fɔl tə wɪntɝz hɑɹɾ ɪn lɛs ðən ə mʌnθ. ðə livz ðət hæd sɝvaɪv ðə lɔŋ sʌmɝz dʒɹaʊt hæd bɪn fɹoʊzən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd tʃeɪnʒ kʌlɝ, ən naʊ ðeɪ ɡlɪsən laɪk stʃɹeɪnʒ, aɪs-kʌvɝɾ ɛmɹəlz ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn. ðə hɔɹsəz ə ðə twɛnti-ɑɾ ɑɹmmɪn ɝaʊn ɪm əkeɪʒənəli stæmpt ə huf ɪn ðə ni-dip snoʊ. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ ɹaɪd ðɪs fɑɹ, ən ðeɪ hæd fɝðɝ tə ɡoʊ wɛðɝ ðɪs deɪ tɝn aʊt ɡʊɾ əɹ ɪl. dɑɹk klaʊdz ɹɔɪl ðə skaɪ tə nɔɹθwɝd. hi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪz wɛðɝ-waɪz ðəɹ tə tɛl ɪm ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ wəd plʌmət bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl. ðeɪ hæd tə bi ʌndɝ ʃɛltɝ baɪ ðɛn.

Winter had come late to Arad Doman very late, but with a vengeance. From summer heat that lingered unnaturally into fall to winter's heart in less than a month. The leaves that had survived the long summer's drought had been frozen before they could change color, and now they glistened like strange, ice-covered emeralds in the morning sun. The horses of the twenty-odd armsmen around him occasionally stamped a hoof in the knee-deep snow. It had been a long ride this far, and they had further to go whether this day turned out good or ill. Dark clouds roiled the sky to northward. He did not need his weather-wise there to tell him the temperature would plummet before nightfall. They had to be under shelter by then.

"nɑɾ əz ɹʌf əz wɪntɝ bɪfɔɹ læst, ɪz ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd" dʒæləm sɛd kwaɪətli. ðə tɔl jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ hæɾ əweɪ ʌv ɹiɾɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldiz maɪn ən ɪz vɔɪs wɑz pɪtʃt fəɹ ði ʌðɝz tə hɪɹ. "ivən soʊ, aɪ səpoʊz səm mɛn wəd bi dʒɹimɪŋ ə mʌld waɪn əbaʊt naʊ. nɑt ðɪs lɑt, ʌv kɔɹs. ɹɪmɑɹkəbli əbstimiəs. ðeɪ ɔl dʒɹɪŋk ti, aɪ bɪliv. koʊl ti. ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ə fju bɝtʃ swɪtʃəz, ðeɪd bi stʃɹɪpɪŋ daʊn fəɹ snoʊ-bæθs."

"Not as rough as winter before last, is it, my Lord" Jaalam said quietly. The tall young officer had away of reading Ituralde's mind and his voice was pitched for the others to hear. "Even so, I suppose some men would be dreaming of mulled wine about now. Not this lot, of course. Remarkably abstemious. They all drink tea, I believe. Cold tea. If they had a few birch switches, they'd be stripping down for snow-baths."

'ðeɪl əv tə kip ðɛɹ kloʊðz ɑn fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ," ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌt ðeɪ maɪt ɡɛt səm koʊl ti tənaɪt, ɪf ðəɹ lʌki." ðət bɹɔɾ ə fju tʃʌkəlz. kwaɪət tʃʌkəlz. hi hæd tʃoʊzən ðiz mɛn wɪð kɛɹ, ən ðeɪ nu əbaʊt nɔɪz ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm.

'They'll have to keep their clothes on for the time being," Ituralde replied dryly, "but they might get some cold tea tonight, if they're lucky." That brought a few chuckles. Quiet chuckles. He had chosen these men with care, and they knew about noise at the wrong time.

hi hɪmsɛlf cʊɾə dʌn wɪð ə stimɪŋ kʌp ə spaɪst waɪn, əɹ ivən ti. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns mɝtʃəns hæd bɹɔt ti tə ɑɹæd dumən. ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns ɛni aʊtlæn mɝtʃən hæd vɛntʃɝd fɝðɝ ðən ðə bɔɹɾɝ wɪð sɑldɑiə. baɪ ðə ɹaɪm nuz ə ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld ɹitʃt hɪm, ɪt wɑz əz steɪl əz læs mʌnθs bɹɛd, ɪf ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝ tə bɪɡɪn. ðət hɑɹdli mæɾɝd, ðoʊ. ɪf ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʃɹuli wɑz dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf, əɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl ɹɪli wɝ biɪŋ kɔl tə keɪɛmlɪn, wɛl, ðə wɝld wəɾ əv tə də wɪθaʊt ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi əntɪl ɑɹæd dumən wɑz hoʊl əɡɛn.

He himself could have done with a steaming cup of spiced wine, or even tea. But it was a long time since merchants had brought tea to Arad Doman. A long time since any outland merchant had ventured further than the border with Saldaea. By the rime news of the outside world reached him, it was as stale as last month's bread, if it was more than rumor to begin. That hardly mattered, though. If the White Tower truly was divided against itself, or men who could channel really were being called to Caemlyn, well, the world would have to do without Rodel Ituralde until Arad Doman was whole again.

fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɑɹæd dumən wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni seɪn mæn tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð. wʌns əɡɛn laɪ ɹivjud ði ɔɹɾɝz i hæd sɛnt, kæɹid baɪ ðə fæstəst ɹaɪɾɝz i hæd, tə ɛvɹi noʊbəl lɔɪəl tə ðə kɪŋ-dɪvaɪɾəd əz ðeɪ wɝ baɪ bæd blʌɾ ən oʊl fjudz, ðeɪ stɪl ʃɛɹd ðət mʌtʃ. ðeɪ wəd ɡæðɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmiz ən ɹaɪd wən ɔɹɾɝz keɪm fɹəm ðə wʊlf; ət list, soʊ lɔŋ əz i hɛl ðə kɪŋz feɪvɝ. ðeɪ wəɾ ivən haɪɾ ɪn ðə maʊntənz ən weɪt, fəɹ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ. oʊ, ðeɪ wəd tʃeɪf, ən səm wəd kɝs ɪz neɪm, bʌt ðeɪ wəɾ oʊbeɪ. ðeɪ nu ðə wʊlf wʌn bæɾəlz. mɔɹ, ðeɪ nu hi wʌn wɔɹz. ðə lɪɾəl wʊlf, ðeɪ kɔld ɪm wən ðeɪ θɔɾ i kəd nɔɹ hɪɹ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ðeɪ dʒɹu ətɛnʃən tə hɪz stætʃɝ-wɛl, nɑt mʌtʃ-soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd wən ən wɛɹ i sɛd.

For the moment, Arad Doman was more than enough for any sane man to go on with. Once again lie reviewed the orders he had sent, carried by the fastest riders he had, to every noble loyal to the King-Divided as they were by bad blood and old feuds, they still shared that much. They would gather their armies and ride when orders came from the Wolf; at least, so long as he held the King's favor. They would even hide in the mountains and wait, for his order. Oh, they would chafe, and some would curse his name, but they would obey. They knew the Wolf won battles. More, they knew he won wars. The Little Wolf, they called him when they thought he could nor hear, but he did not care whether they drew attention to his stature-well, not much-so long as they rode when and where he said.

vɛɹi sun ðeɪ wəd bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɑɹd, muvɪŋ tə sɛɾ ə tʃɹæp ðət wəd nɑt spɹɪŋ fəɹ mʌnθs. ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ tʃæns i wɑz teɪkɪŋ. kɑmplɛks plænz hæd mɛni weɪz tə fɔl əpɑɹt, ən ðɪs plæn hæd leɪɝz ɪnsaɪd leɪɝz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd bi ɹuən bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɪɡæn ɪf i feɪl tə pɹəvaɪd ðə beɪt. əɹ ɪf sʌmwʌn ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝ tə ɪveɪd kɝiɝz fɹəm ðə kɪŋ. ðeɪ ɔl nu hɪz ɹizənz, ðoʊ, ən ivən ðə moʊst stɪf-nɛkt ʃɛɹd ðɛm, ðoʊ fju wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə spik ə ðə mæɾɝ əlaʊd. hi hɪmsɛlf hæd muv laɪk ə ɹeɪθ ɹeɪsɪŋ ɑn ə stɔɹm sɪns i ɹəsivd ælsələmz leɪɾəst kəmænd. ɪn ɪz sliv ðə foʊldəd peɪpɝ leɪ tʌkt əbʌv ðə peɪl leɪs ðət fɛl ɑntu hɪz stil-bækt ɡɔnlət. ðeɪ hæd wʌn læs tʃæns, wʌn vɛɹi smɔl tʃæns, tə seɪv ɑɹæd dumən. pɝhæps ivən tə seɪv ælsələm fɹəm hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pʊɾ ənʌðɝ mæn ɑn ðə θɹoʊn ɪn ɪz pleɪs. hi hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd ɹulɝ, fəɹ oʊvɝ twɛnti jɪɹz. ðə laɪt sɛn ðəɾ i kəd bi əɡɛn.

Very soon they would be riding hard, moving to set a trap that would not spring for months. It was a long chance he was taking. Complex plans had many ways to fall apart, and this plan had layers inside layers. Everything would be ruined before it began if he failed to provide the bait. Or if someone ignored his order to evade couriers from the King. They all knew his reasons, though, and even the most stiff-necked shared them, though few were willing to speak of the matter aloud. He himself had moved like a wraith racing on a storm since he received Alsalam's latest command. In his sleeve the folded paper lay tucked above the pale lace that fell onto his steel-backed gauntlet. They had one last chance, one very small chance, to save Arad Doman. Perhaps even to save Alsalam from himself before the Council of Merchants decided to put another man on the throne in his place. He had been a good ruler, for over twenty years. The Light send that he could be again.

ə laʊd kɹæk tə ðə saʊθ sɛn ɪɾɝɑldiz hæn tə daɪ hɪlt ə hɪz lɔŋzɔɝd. ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪn kɹik ə lɛðɝ ən mɛɾəl əz ʌðɝz iz ðɛɹ wɛpənz. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, saɪləns. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz əz stɪl əz ə fɹoʊzən tum. oʊnli ə lɪm bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ə snoʊ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɹɪlæks əz mʌtʃ əz i hæd ɹɪlækst sɪns ðə teɪlz keɪm nɔɹθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə skaɪ ət fɑlm.

A loud crack to the south sent Ituralde's hand to die hilt of his longsword. There was a faint creak of leather and metal as others eased their weapons. For the rest, silence. The forest was as still as a frozen tomb. Only a limb breaking under the weight of snow. After a moment, he let himself relax as much as he had relaxed since the tales came north of the Dragon Reborn appearing in the sky at Falme.

pɝhæps ðə mæn ɹɪli wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, pɝhæps i ɹɪli hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ðə tʃɹuθ, ðoʊz teɪlz hæd sɛɾ ɑɹæd dumən ɑn faɪɝ.

Perhaps the man really was the Dragon Reborn, perhaps he really had appeared in the sky, but whatever the truth, those tales had set Arad Doman on fire.

ɪɾɝɑldi wɑz ʃʊɹ i cʊɾə pʊɾ aʊt ðət faɪɝ, ɡɪvən ə fɹiɝ hænd. ɪt wɑz nɑt boʊstɪŋ tə θɪŋk soʊ. hi nu wʌɾ i kəd du, wɪð ə bæɾəl, ə kæmpeɪn, əɹ ə wɔɹ. bʌɾ ɛvɝ sɪns ðə kaʊnsəl hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðə kɪŋ wəd bi seɪfɝ smʌɡəld aʊɾ ə bændɑɹ ɛbən, ælsələm sim tə hæv teɪkən ɪndə hɪz hɛd ðəɾ i wɑz ðə ɹibɝθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. hɪz sɪɡnətʃɝ ən sil hæd mɑɹk skɔɹz ə bæɾəl ɔɹɾɝz sɪns, hɛɾɪŋ aʊt fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ ðə kaʊnsəl hæɾ ɪm hɪɾən. ðeɪ wəd nɑt: seɪ wɛɹ ðət wɑz, ivən tə ɪɾɝɑldi hɪmsɛlf. ɛvɹi wʊmən ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ðəɾ i kənfɹʌntəd wɛn flæt-aɪɾ ən ɪveɪsɪv əɾ ɛni mɛnʃən ə ðə kɪŋ. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪliv ðeɪ dɪd nɔɹ noʊ wɛɹ ælsələm wɑz. ə ɹɪdɪkjələs θɔt, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə kaʊnsəl kɛpt ən ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪ ɑn ðə kɪŋ. ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪliv ðə mɝtʃən haʊsəz ɪntɝfɪɹd tu mʌtʃ, jɛɾ i wɪʃt ðeɪ wəɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ naʊ. waɪ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn saɪlənt wɑz ə mɪstɝi, fəɹ ə kɪŋ u dæmədʒ tʃɹeɪd dɪd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. hi wɑz lɔɪəl tə hɪz oʊðz, ən ælsələm wɑz ə fɹɛnd, bɪsaɪdz, bʌt ði ɔɹɾɝz ðə kɪŋ sɛn kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn bɛɾɝ ɹɪɾən tə ətʃiv keɪɑs. nɔɹ kəd ðeɪ bi ɪɡnɔɹd. ælsələm wɑz ðə kɪŋ. bʌɾ i hæd kəmændəɾ ɪɾɝɑldi tə mɑɹtʃ nɔɹθ wɪð ɔl pɑsəbəl spiɾ əɡɛnst ə ɡɹeɪt ɡæðɝɪŋ ə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ðəɾ ælsələm səpoʊzədli nu ʌv fɹəm sikɹət spaɪz; ðən tɛn deɪz leɪɾɝ, wɪð noʊ dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn jɛɾ ɪn saɪt, ən ɔɹɾɝ keɪm tə muv saʊθ əɡɛn, wɪð ɔl pɑsəbəl spid, əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ ðət nɛvɝ mətɪɹiəlaɪzd. hi hæd bɪn kəmændəd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɪz fɔɹsɪz tə dɪfɛn bændɑɹ ɛbən wən ə θɹi-pɹɔŋd ətæk maɪɾ əv ɛndəɾ ɪɾ ɔl ən tə dɪvaɪɾ əm wən ə hæmɝ bloʊ cʊɾə dʌn ðə seɪm, tə hɛɹi ɡɹaʊn i nu ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn hæɾ əbændənd, ən tə mɑɹtʃ əweɪ fɹəm wɛɹ i nu ðeɪ kæmpt. wɝs, ælsələmz ɔɹɾɝz ɔfən hæd ɡɔn dɝɛkli tə ðə paʊɝfəl noʊbəlz u wɝ səpoʊz tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ ɪɾɝɑldi, sɛndɪŋ mətʃɹ ɪn ðɪs dɝɛkʃən, tikəl ɪn ðæt, ɹɑmən ɪn ə θɝd.

Ituralde was sure he could have put out that fire, given a freer hand. It was not boasting to think so. He knew what he could do, with a battle, a campaign, or a war. But ever since the Council had decided the King would be safer smuggled out of Bandar Eban, Alsalam seemed to have taken into his head that he was the rebirth of Artur Hawkwing. His signature and seal had marked scores of battle orders since, heading out from wherever the Council had him hidden. They would not: say where that was, even to Ituralde himself. Every woman on the Council that he confronted went flat-eyed and evasive at any mention of the King. He could almost believe they did nor know where Alsalam was. A ridiculous thought, of course. The Council kept an unblinking eye on the King. Ituralde had always believed the merchant Houses interfered too much, yet he wished they would interfere now. Why they remained silent was a mystery, for a king who damaged trade did not remain long on the throne. He was loyal to his oaths, and Alsalam was a friend, besides, but the orders the King sent could not have been better written to achieve chaos. Nor could they be ignored. Alsalam was the King. But he had commanded Ituralde to march north with all possible speed against a great gathering of Dragonsworn that Alsalam supposedly knew of from secret spies; then ten days later, with no Dragonsworn yet in sight, an order came to move south again, with all possible speed, against another gathering that never materialized. He had been commanded to concentrate his forces to defend Bandar Eban when a three-pronged attack might have ended it all and to divide them when a hammer blow could have done the same, to harry ground he knew the Dragonsworn had abandoned, and to march away from where he knew they camped. Worse, Alsalam's orders often had gone directly to the powerful nobles who were supposed to be following Ituralde, sending Machir in this direction, Teacal in that, Rahman in a third.

fɔɹ ɹaɪmz, pɪtʃt bæɾəlz hæd ɹɪzʌltɪd fɹəm pɑɹts ə ði ɑɹmi blʌndɝɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə naɪt waɪl muvɪŋ tə ðə kɪŋz ɪkspɹɛs kəmæn ən ɪkspɛktɪŋ nʌn bʌɾ ɛnəmiz əhɛd. ən ɔl ðə waɪl ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ɡeɪnd nʌmbɝz, ən kɑnfəɾəns, ɪɾɝɑldi hæd hæɾ ɪz tʃɹaɪəmfs-æt soʊlɑnʒ ən mæsin, ət leɪk səmɑl ən kændəlmɝ, ðə lɔɹdz ə kɑɾɝ hæd lɝnd nɔɹ tə sɛl ðə pɹɑɾəkts ə ðɛɹ maɪnz ən fɔɹdʒɪz tə ði ɛnəmiz ʌv ɑɹæd dumən-bʌɾ ɔlweɪz, ælsələmz ɔɹɾɝz weɪstəɾ ɪz ɡeɪnz.

Four rimes, pitched battles had resulted from parts of the army blundering into one another in the night while moving to the King's express command and expecting none but enemies ahead. And all the while the Dragonsworn gained numbers, and confidence, Ituralde had had his triumphs-at Solanje and Maseen, at Lake Somal and Kandelmar, the Lords of Katar had learned nor to sell the products of their mines and forges to the enemies of Arad Doman-but always, Alsalam's orders wasted his gains.

ðɪs læst ɔɹɾɝ wɑz dɪfɹənt, ðoʊ. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ə ɡɹeɪ mæn hæd kɪld leɪɾi tuvə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp ɪt fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ hɪm. waɪ ðə ʃædoʊ maɪt fɪɹ ðɪs ɔɹɾɝ mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ wɑz ə mɪstɝi, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɹizən tə muv swɪfli. bɪfɔɹ ælsələm ɹitʃt ɪm wɪð ənʌðɝ. ðɪs ɔɹɾɝ oʊpən mɛni pɑsəbɪləɾiz, ən i hæd kənsɪɾɝd ɛvɹi læst wʌn i kəd si. bʌt ɡʊd wʌnz ɔl stɑɹɾəd hɪɹ, tədeɪ. wən smɔl tʃænsəz ə səksɛs wɝ ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪnd, jə hæd tə siz ðɛm.

This last order was different, though. For one thing, a Gray Man had killed Lady Tuva trying to stop it from reaching him. Why the Shadow might fear this order more than any other was a mystery, yet it was all the more reason to move swiftly. Before Alsalam reached him with another. This order opened many possibilities, and he had considered every last one he could see. But good ones all started here, today. When small chances of success were all that remained, you had to seize them.

ə snoʊdʒəz stʃɹaɪɾənt kɹaɪ ɹæŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ðən ə sɛkən taɪm, ə θɝd. kʌpɪŋ ɪz hænz ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ, ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə θɹi hɑɹʃ kɔlz. moʊməns leɪɾɝ ə ʃæɡi, peɪl dæpəl ɡɛldɪŋ əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, hɪz ɹaɪɾɝ ɪn ə waɪt kloʊk stʃɹikt wɪð blæk. mæn ən hɔɹs əlaɪk wʊɾə bɪn hɑɹd tə si ɪn ðə snoʊi fɔɹəs hæd ðeɪ bɪn stændɪŋ stɪl. ðə ɹaɪɾɝ pʊld ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪɾɝɑldi. ə stɑki mæn, hi wɔɹ oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl sɔɹd, wɪð ə ʃɔɹt bleɪd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə keɪs baʊ ən ə kwɪvɝ fæsən tə hɪz sæɾəl.

A snowjay's strident cry rang out in the distance, then a second time, a third. Cupping his hands around his mouth, Ituralde repeated the three harsh calls. Moments later a shaggy, pale dapple gelding appeared out of the trees, his rider in a white cloak streaked with black. Man and horse alike would have been hard to see in the snowy forest had they been standing still. The rider pulled up beside Ituralde. A stocky man, he wore only a single sword, with a short blade, and there was a cased bow and a quiver fastened to his saddle.

"lʊks laɪk ðeɪ ɔl keɪm, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛɾ ɪn ɪz pɝmənənli hɔɹs vɔɪs, pʊʃɪŋ ɪz kaʊl bæk fɹəm ɪz hɛd. sʌmwʌn hæd kɹaɪd tə hæŋ doʊnʒəl wən i wɑz jʌŋ, ðoʊ ðə ɹizən wɑz lɔst ɪn ðə jɪɹz. wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ə hɪz ʃɔɹt-kɹɑp hɛɹ wɑz aɪɝn ɡɹeɪ. ðə dɑɹk lɛðɝ pɑɹtʃ kʌvɝɪŋ ðə sɑkəɾ ə hɪz ɹaɪɾ aɪ wɑz ə ɹɛmnən ʌv ənʌðɝ juθfəl skɹeɪp. wʌn aɪ əɹ tu, ðoʊ, hi wɑz ðə bɛst skaʊɾ ɪɾɝɑldi hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. "moʊst ɛniweɪz," hi wɛn ɑn. "ðeɪ pʊt tu ɹɪŋz ə sɛntʃɹiz ɝaʊn ðə lɑdʒ, wʌn ɪnsaɪd ði ʌðɝ. jə kən si ðɛm ə maɪl ə bʌt noʊbɑdi wɪl ɡɛt kloʊs wɪθaʊɾ əm ət ðə lɑdʒ hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ ɪn taɪm tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. baɪ ðə tʃɹæks, ðeɪ dɪdn bɹɪŋ noʊ mɔɹ mɛn ðən jə sɛd ðeɪ kʊd, nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kaʊnt. kɔɹs," hi æɾəd ɹaɪli "ðæt stɪl livz jə aʊtnʌmbɝɾ ə fɛɹ bɪt." ɪɾɝɑldi nɑɾəd. hi hæɾ ɔfɝd ðə waɪt ɹɪbən, ən ðə mɛn i wɑz tə mit hæɾ æksɛptɪd.

"Looks like they all came, my Lord," he said in his permanently hoarse voice, pushing his cowl back from his head. Someone had cried to hang Donjel when he was young, though the reason was lost in the years. What remained of his short-cropped hair was iron gray. The dark leather parch covering the socket of his right eye was a remnant of another youthful scrape. One eye or two, though, he was the best scout Ituralde had ever known. "Most anyways," he went on. "They put two rings of sentries around the lodge, one inside the other. You can see them a mile of but nobody will get close without them at the lodge hearing of it in time to get away. By the tracks, they didn't bring no more men than you said they could, not enough to count. Course," he added wryly "that still leaves you outnumbered a fair bit." Ituralde nodded. He had offered the White Ribbon, and the men he was to meet had accepted.

θɹi deɪz wən mɛn plɛdʒd ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, baɪ ðɛɹ soʊlz ən hoʊp ə sælveɪʃən, nɑt tə dʒɹɔ ə wɛpən əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ əɹ ʃɛd blʌd. ðə waɪt ɹɪbən hæd nɑt bɪn tɛstəɾ ɪn ðɪs wɔɹ, haʊɛvɝ, ən ðiz deɪz, səm mɛn hæd stʃɹeɪnʒ aɪdiəz ʌv wɛɹ sælveɪʃən leɪ. ðoʊz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, fəɹ ɪnstəns. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn kɔld ə ɡæmblɝ, ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt. ðə tʃɹɪk wɑz ɪn noʊɪŋ wʌt ɹɪsks jə kəd teɪk. ən səmtaɪmz, ɪn noʊɪŋ wɪtʃ wʌnz jə hæd tə teɪk.

Three days when men pledged under the Light, by their souls and hope of salvation, not to draw a weapon against another or shed blood. The White Ribbon had not been tested in this war, however, and these days, some men had strange ideas of where salvation lay. Those who called themselves Dragonsworn, for instance. He had always been called a gambler, though he was not. The trick was in knowing what risks you could take. And sometimes, in knowing which ones you had to take.

pʊlɪŋ ə pækət soʊn ɪndə ɔɪl sɪlk fɹəm ɪz butɑp, hi hændəɾ ɪt tə doʊnʒəl. ɪf aɪ doʊn ɹitʃ kɔɹən fɔɹɾ ɪn tu deɪz, teɪk ðɪs tə maɪ waɪf."

Pulling a packet sewn into oiled silk from his boottop, he handed it to Donjel. If I don't reach Coran Ford in two days, take this to my wife."

ðə skaʊɝ tʌk ðə pækət sʌmwɛɹ bɪniθ ɪz kloʊk, tʌtʃt ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ən tɝn ɪz hɔɹs wɛst. hi hæd kæɹiɾ ɪts laɪk fəɹ ɪɾɝɑldi bɪfɔɹ, juʒəwəli ɑn ði iv ə bæɾəl. ðə laɪt sɛn ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə taɪm tæmsən wəɾ əv tə oʊpən ðət pækət. ʃi wəd kʌm æftɝ hɪm-ʃi hæd toʊld ɪm soʊ-ðə fɝst ɪnsəɾənt ɛvɝ ə ðə lɪvɪŋ hɔntɪŋ ðə dɛd, "dʒæləm," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd, "lɛɾ əs si wʌt weɪts ət leɪɾi oʊsænəz hʌntɪŋ lɑdʒ." əz i hil dɑɹt fɔɹwɝd, ði ʌðɝ fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn hɪm.

The scour tucked the packet somewhere beneath his cloak, touched his forehead, and turned his horse west. He had carried its like for Ituralde before, usually on the eve of battle. The Light send this was not the time Tamsin would have to open that packet. She would come after him-she had told him so-the first incident ever of the living haunting the dead, "Jaalam," Ituralde said, "let us see what waits at Lady Osana's hunting lodge." As he heeled Dart forward, the other fell in behind him.

ðə sʌn ɹoʊz tə ɪts haɪɾ ən bɪɡæn əɡɛn tə dɪsɛn əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd. ðə dɑɹk klaʊdz ɪn ðə nɔɹθ muv kloʊsɝ, ən ðə tʃɪl bɪt dipɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊn bʌt ðə kɹʌntʃ ə hʊvz bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊkɹʌst. ðə fɔɹəst simd ɛmpti seɪv fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz. hi dɪd nɑt si ɛni ʌv ðə sɛntʃɹiz doʊnʒəl hæd spoʊkən ʌv. ðə mænz əpɪnjən ʌv wʌt kəd bi sin fɹəm ə maɪl dɪfɝd fɹəm ðəɾ ə moʊst. ðeɪ wəd bi ɪkspɛktɪŋ hɪm, ʌv kɔɹs. ən wɑtʃɪŋ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i wɑz nɑt fɑloʊd baɪ ən ɑɹmi, waɪt ɹɪbən əɹ noʊ waɪt ɹɪbən. ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv əm laɪkli hæd ɹizənz ðeɪ fɛl səfɪʃən tə fɛðɝ ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi wɪð æɹoʊz. ə lɔɹd maɪt plɛdʒ ðə waɪt ɹɪbən fəɹ ɪz mɛn, bʌt wəɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz fil baʊnd? səmtaɪmz, ðəɹ wɝ tʃænsəz jə dʒʌs hæd tə teɪk. əbaʊt mɪd-æftɝnun, oʊsænəz soʊ-kɔl hʌntɪŋ lɑdʒ lum sʌɾənli aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, ə mæs ə peɪl taʊɝz ən slɛndɝ, pɔɪntəd doʊmz ðət wʊɾə fɪɾəd wɛl əmʌŋ ðə pæləsəz ə bændɑɹ ɛbən ɪtsɛlf. hɝ hʌntɪŋ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn fəɹ mɛn əɹ paʊɝ, hɝ tʃɹoʊfiz numɝəs ən noʊt-wɝði dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɹɛləɾɪv juθ, ən ðə "hʌns" ðət hæd teɪkən pleɪs hɪɹ wʊɾə ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊz ivən ɪn ðə kæpəɾəl. ðə lɑdʒ leɪ dɛsələt, naʊ.

The sun rose to its height and began again to descend as they rode. The dark clouds in the north moved closer, and the chill bit deeper. There was no sound but the crunch of hooves breaking through the snowcrust. The forest seemed empty save for themselves. He did not see any of the sentries Donjel had spoken of. The man's opinion of what could be seen from a mile differed from that of most. They would be expecting him, of course. And watching to make sure he was not followed by an army, White Ribbon or no White Ribbon. A good many of them likely had reasons they felt sufficient to feather Rodel Ituralde with arrows. A lord might pledge the White Ribbon for his men, but would all of those feel bound? Sometimes, there were chances you just had to take. About mid-afternoon, Osana's so-called hunting lodge loomed suddenly out of the trees, a mass of pale towers and slender, pointed domes that would have fitted well among the palaces of Bandar Eban itself. Her hunting had always been for men or power, her trophies numerous and note-worthy despite her relative youth, and the "hunts" that had taken place here would have raised eyebrows even in the capital. The lodge lay desolate, now.

bɹoʊkən wɪndoʊz ɡeɪp laɪk maʊðz wɪð dʒæɡd tiθ. nʌn ʃoʊɾ ə ɡlɪmɝ ə laɪɾ əɹ muvmənt.

Broken windows gaped like mouths with jagged teeth. None showed a glimmer of light or movement.

ðə snoʊ kʌvɝɪŋ ðə klɪɹd ɡɹaʊn ɝaʊn ðə lɑdʒ hæd bɪn wɛl tʃɹæmpəl baɪ hɔɹsəz, haʊɛvɝ. ði ɔɹneɪt bɹæsbaʊnd ɡeɪts ə ðə meɪn kɔɹtʃjɑɹd stʊɾ oʊpən, ən i ɹoʊd θɹu wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ, fɑloʊd baɪ hɪz mɛn. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz klæɾɝd ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, wɛɹ ðə snoʊ hæd bɪn biɾən tə slʌʃ. noʊ sɝvəns keɪm aʊt tə ɡɹit hɪm, nɑt ðəɾ i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛni. oʊsænə hæd vænɪʃt ɝli ɪn ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ðət naʊ ʃʊk ɑɹæd dumən laɪk ə dɔɡ ʃeɪkɪŋ ə ɹæt, ən əɹ sɝvəns hæd dʒɹɪftəd kwɪkli tə ʌðɝz ə hɝ haʊs, teɪkɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ pleɪsəz ðeɪ kəd faɪnd. ðiz deɪz, ðə mæstɝləs stɑɹvd, əɹ tɝn bændət. əɹ dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn. dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɹɔd mɑɹbəl stɛɹweɪ ət ði ɛn ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, hi hændəd dɑɹts ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə hɪz ɑɹmmɪn, ən dʒæləm ɔɹɾɝd ðə mɛn tə teɪk ʃɛltɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd faɪn ɪt fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ən ði ænəməlz. aɪɪŋ ðə mɑɹbəl bælkəniz ən waɪd wɪndoʊz ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ðeɪ muvd əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə kɹɔsboʊ boʊl bɪtwin ðə ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. wʌn sɛɾ ə steɪbəl dɔɹz stʊd slaɪtli ədʒɑɹ, bʌɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə koʊld, ðeɪ dɪvaɪɾəd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪtwin ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, hʌɾəlɪŋ wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd kip wɑtʃ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ɪf ðə wɝs keɪm, pɝhæps ə fju maɪt meɪk ɪɾ aʊt, ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz ɡɔnləts, hi tʌkt əm bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt ən tʃɛkt ɪz leɪs əz i klaɪm ðə stɛɹz wɪð dʒæləm. snoʊ ðət hæd bɪn tʃɹɑɾən ʌndɝfʊɾ ən fɹoʊzən əɡɛn kɹækəl bɪniθ ɪz buts. hi ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm lʊkɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ bʌt stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. hi mʌst əpɪɹ supɹiməli əʃʊɹd, əz ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pɑsəbɪləɾi ɪvɛns ʃəd ɡoʊ ʌðɝ ðən i ɪkspɛktəd. kɑnfəɾəns wɑz wʌn ki tə vɪktɝi. ði ʌðɝ saɪd bɪlivɪŋ jə wɝ kɑnfəɾənt wɑz səmtaɪmz ɔlmoʊst əz ɡʊɾ əz æktʃəli  biɪŋ kɑnfəɾənt. ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz, dʒæləm pʊld oʊpən wʌn ə ðə tɔl, kɑɹv dɔɹz baɪ ɪts ɡɪldɪd ɹɪŋ. ɪɾɝɑldi tʌtʃt ɪz bjuɾi spɑt wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ɪn pleɪs-hɪz tʃiks wɝ tu koʊl tə fil ðə blæk vɛlvət stɑɹ klɪŋɪŋ-bɪfɔɹ i stɛpt ɪnsaɪd. əz sɛlf-əʃʊɹɾ əz wʊɾə əv bɪn əɾ ə bɔl.

The snow covering the cleared ground around the lodge had been well trampled by horses, however. The ornate brassbound gates of the main courtyard stood open, and he rode through without slowing, followed by his men. The horses' hooves clattered on the paving stones, where the snow had been beaten to slush. No servants came out to greet him, not that he had expected any. Osana had vanished early in the troubles that now shook Arad Doman like a dog shaking a rat, and her servants had drifted quickly to others of her house, taking whatever places they could find. These days, the masterless starved, or turned bandit. Or Dragonsworn. Dismounting in front of the broad marble stairway at the end of the courtyard, he handed Dart's reins to one of his armsmen, and Jaalam ordered the men to take shelter where they could find it for themselves and the animals. Eyeing the marble balconies and wide windows that surrounded the courtyard, they moved as if expecting a crossbow bolt between the shoulder blades. One set of stable doors stood slightly ajar, but in spite of the cold, they divided themselves between the corners of the courtyard, huddling with the horses where they could keep watch in every direction. If the worst came, perhaps a few might make it out, removing his gauntlets, he tucked them behind his belt and checked his lace as he climbed the stairs with Jaalam. Snow that had been trodden underfoot and frozen again crackled beneath his boots. He refrained from looking anywhere but straight ahead. He must appear supremely assured, as though there were no possibility events should go other than he expected. Confidence was one key to victory. The other side believing you were confident was sometimes almost as good as actually being confident. At the head of the stairs, Jaalam pulled open one of the tall, carved doors by its gilded ring. Ituralde touched his beauty spot with a finger to make sure it was in place-his cheeks were too cold to feel the black velvet star clinging-before he stepped inside. As self-assured as he would have been at a ball.

ðə kævɝnəs ɛntʃɹi hɔl wɑz əz aɪsi əz ði aʊtsaɪd. ðɛɹ bɹɛθ meɪd fɛðɝd mɪsts. ənlɪt, ðə speɪs simd ɔlɹɛɾi ɹɛðd ɪn twaɪlaɪt. ðə flɔɹ wɑz ə kʌlɝfəl moʊzeɪɪk ə hʌntɝz ən ænəməlz, ðə taɪlz tʃɪpt ɪn pleɪsəz, əz ðoʊ hɛvi weɪts hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡd oʊvɝ ðɛm, əɹ pɝhæps dʒɹɑpt. əsaɪd fɹəm ə sɪŋɡəl tɑpəl plɪnθ ðət maɪt wʌns əv hɛld ə lɑɹdʒ veɪs əɹ ə smɔl stætʃu, ðə hɔl wɑz bɛɹ.

The cavernous entry hall was as icy as the outside. Their breath made feathered mists. Unlit, the space seemed already wreathed in twilight. The floor was a colorful mosaic of hunters and animals, the tiles chipped in places, as though heavy weights had been dragged over them, or perhaps dropped. Aside from a single toppled plinth that might once have held a large vase or a small statue, the hall was bare.

wʌt ðə sɝvəns hæd nɑt teɪkən wən ðeɪ flɛd hæd lɔŋ sɪns bɪn luɾəd baɪ bændəts. ə sɪŋɡəl mæn əweɪɾəd ðɛm, waɪt-hɛɹɾ ən mɔɹ ɡɔn ðən wən ɪɾɝɑldi hæd læst sin hɪm. hɪz bɹɛstpleɪt wɑz bæɾɝd, ən ɪz ɪɹɪŋ wɑz dʒʌst ə smɔl ɡoʊl hup, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz ɪmækjulɪt, ən ðə spɑɹklɪŋ ɹɛd kɔɹɾɝ mun bɪsaɪɾ ɪz lɛft aɪ wʊɾə ɡɔn wɛl ət kɔɹt, ɪn bɛɾɝ taɪmz. "baɪ ðə laɪt, bi wɛlkəm ʌndɝ ðə waɪt ɹɪbən, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi," hi sɛd fɔɹməli, wɪð ə slaɪt baʊ. "baɪ ðə laɪt, aɪ kʌm ʌndɝ ðə waɪt ɹɪbən, lɔɹd ʃɪmɹɑn," ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪplaɪd, meɪkɪŋ ɪz kɝɾəsi ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ʃɪmɹɑn hæd bɪn wʌn ʌv ælsələmz moʊs tʃɹʌstɪɾ ædvaɪzɝz. əntɪl i dʒɔɪn ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, ət list. naʊ hi stʊd haɪ ɪn ðɛɹ kaʊnsəlz. "maɪ ɑɹmsmən ɪz dʒæləm niʃɝ, ɑnɝ-baʊn tə haʊs ɪɾɝɑldi əz ɑɹ ɔl u keɪm wɪð mi." ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ haʊs ɪɾɝɑldi bɪfɔɹ ɹoʊɾəl, bʌt ʃɪmɹɑn ænsɝd dʒæləmz baʊ, hæn tə hɑɹt. "ɑnɝ bi tə ɑnɝ. wɪl jə əkʌmpəni mi, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi" hi sɛɾ əz i stʃɹeɪɾənd.

What the servants had not taken when they fled had long since been looted by bandits. A single man awaited them, white-haired and more gaunt than when Ituralde had last seen him. His breastplate was battered, and his earring was just a small gold hoop, but his face was immaculate, and the sparkling red quarter moon beside his left eye would have gone well at court, in better times. "By the Light, be welcome under the White Ribbon, Lord Ituralde," he said formally, with a slight bow. "By the Light, I come under the White Ribbon, Lord Shimron," Ituralde replied, making his courtesy in return. Shimron had been one of Alsalam's most trusted advisers. Until he joined the Dragonsworn, at least. Now he stood high in their councils. "My armsman is Jaalam Nishur, honor-bound to House Ituralde as are all who came with me." There had been no House Ituralde before Rodel, but Shimron answered Jaalam's bow, hand to heart. "Honor be to honor. Will you accompany me, Lord Ituralde" he said as he straightened.

ðə ɡɹeɪt dɔɹz tə ðə bɔlɹum wɝ ɡɔn fɹəm ðɛɹ hɪnʒɪz, ðoʊ ɪɾɝɑldi kəd hɑɹdli ɪmædʒən bændəts luɾɪŋ ðoʊz, fəɹ ðeɪ lɛft ə tɔl pɔɪntəɾ ɑɹtʃ waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ tɛn mɛn tə pæs. wɪðɪn ðə wɪndoʊləs oʊvəl ɹum, hæf ə hʌnʒɹəd læntɝnz ʌv ɛvɹi saɪz ən sɔɹt biɾ ət ʃædoʊz, ðoʊ ðə laɪt bɛɹli ɹitʃt ðə doʊm silɪŋ. sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ ə waɪɾ ɪkspæns ə flɔɹ, tu ɡɹups ə mɛn stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə peɪntəd wɔlz, ən ɪf ðə waɪt ɹɪbən hæɾ ɪndust əm tə liv ɔf hɛlməts, ɔl tu hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ wɝ ɑɹmɝɾ ʌðɝwaɪz, ən sɝɾənli noʊ wʌn hæd pʊɾ əsaɪɾ ɪz sɔɹdz. tə wʌn saɪd wɝ ə fju dəmɑni lɔɹdz əz paʊɝfəl əz ʃɪmɹɑn-ɹədʒɑbi, weɪkeɪɾə, æŋkɑɹ-itʃ sɝaʊndəd baɪ hɪz klʌstɝ ə lɛsɝ lɔɹdz ən swɔɹn kɑmənɝz, ən smɔlɝ klʌstɝz, əz fju əz tu əɹ θɹi, mɛni kənteɪnɪŋ noʊ noʊbəlz əɾ ɔl. ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn hæd kaʊnsəlz, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəmændɝ. stɪl, itʃ ə ðoʊz mɛn wɑz ə liɾɝ ɪn ɪz oʊn ɹaɪt, səm kaʊntɪŋ ðɛɹ fɑloʊɝz ɪn skɔɹz, ə fju ɪn θaʊzənz. nʌn əpɪɹd hæpi tə bi wɛɹ i wɑz, ən wʌn əɹ tu ʃɑt ɡlɛɹz əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ, tə wɛɹ fɪfti əɹ sɪksti tæɹɑbənɝz stʊɾ ɪn wʌn sɑləd mæs ən skaʊl bæk. dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn ðeɪ maɪɾ ɔl bi jɛt ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl lʌv lɔs bɪtwin dəmɑni ən tæɹɑbənɝz. ɪɾɝɑldi ɔlmoʊst smaɪld ət ðə saɪɾ ə ði aʊtləndɝz, ðoʊ.

The great doors to the ballroom were gone from their hinges, though Ituralde could hardly imagine bandits looting those, for they left a tall pointed arch wide enough for ten men to pass. Within the windowless oval room, half a hundred lanterns of every size and sort beat at shadows, though the light barely reached the domed ceiling. Separated by a wide expanse of floor, two groups of men stood against the painted walls, and if the White Ribbon had induced them to leave off helmets, all two hundred or more were armored otherwise, and certainly no one had put aside his swords. To one side were a few Domani lords as powerful as Shimron-Rajabi, Wakeda, Ankaer-each surrounded by his cluster of lesser lords and sworn commoners, and smaller clusters, as few as two or three, many containing no nobles at all. The Dragonsworn had councils, but no one commander. Still, each of those men was a leader in his own right, some counting their followers in scores, a few in thousands. None appeared happy to be where he was, and one or two shot glares across the floor, to where fifty or sixty Taraboners stood in one solid mass and scowled back. Dragonsworn they might all be yet there was little love lost between Domani and Taraboners. Ituralde almost smiled at the sight of the outlanders, though.

hi hæd nɑt dɛɹd tə kaʊn ɑn hæf soʊ mɛni əpɪɹɪŋ tədeɪ.

He had not dared to count on half so many appearing today.

"lɔɹd ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi kʌmz ʌndɝ ðə waɪt ɹɪbən." ʃɪmɹɑnz vɔɪs ɹæŋ θɹu ðə læntɝn ʃædoʊz. "lɛt huɛvɝ meɪ θɪŋk ə vaɪələns sɝtʃ ɪz hɑɹt, ən kənsɪɾɝ ɪz soʊl." ən ðət wɑz ði ɛn ə fɔɹmæləɾi.

"Lord Rodel Ituralde comes under the White Ribbon." Shimron's voice rang through the lantern shadows. "Let whoever may think of violence search his heart, and consider his soul." And that was the end of formality.

"waɪ dʌz lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi ɔfɝ ðə waɪt ɹɪbən?" weɪkeɪɾə dɪmændəd, wʌn hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz lɔŋzɔɝɾ ən ði ʌðɝ ɪn ə fɪst əɾ ɪz saɪd. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə tɔl mæn, ðoʊ kɔlɝ ðən ɪɾɝɑldi bʌɾ əz hɔɾi əz ɪf i hɛl ðə θɹoʊn hɪmsɛlf. wɪmən hæd kɔld ɪm bjuɾəfəl wʌns. naʊ ə slæntɪŋ blæk skɑɹf kʌvɝd ðə sɑkəɾ ə hɪz mɪsɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aɪ, ən ɪz bjuɾi-spɑt wɑz ə blæk æɹoʊhɛd pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə θɪk skɑɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz tʃik ʌp ɑntu hɪz fɔɹhɛd. "dʌz i ɪntɛn tə dʒɔɪn ʌs? əɹ æsk əs tə sɝɛndɝ? ɔl noʊ ðə wʊlf ɪz boʊld əz wɛl əz diviəs. ɪz i ðət boʊld?" ə ɹʌmbəl ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə mɛn ɑn ɪz saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, pɑɹt mɝθ, pɑɹɾ æŋɡɝ.

"Why does Lord Ituralde offer the White Ribbon?" Wakeda demanded, one hand gripping the hilt of his longsword and the other in a fist at his side. He was not a tall man, though caller than Ituralde but as haughty as if he held the throne himself. Women had called him beautiful once. Now a slanting black scarf covered the socket of his missing right eye, and his beauty-spot was a black arrowhead pointing at the thick scar running from his cheek up onto his forehead. "Does he intend to join us? Or ask us to surrender? All know the Wolf is bold as well as devious. Is he that bold?" A rumble rose among the men on his side of the room, part mirth, part anger.

ɪɾɝɑldi klæspt ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk tə kip fɹəm fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə ɹubi ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ. ðət wɑz waɪdli noʊn əz ə saɪn ðət laɪ wɑz æŋɡɹi, ən səmtaɪmz i dɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn pɝpəs, bʌɾ i niɾəd tə pɹizɛn ə kɑm feɪs, naʊ. ivən waɪl ðə mæn spoʊk pæst ɪz ɪɹ! noʊ. kɑm. duəlz wɝ ɛntɝɾ ɪndə ɪn æŋɡɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz hɪɹ tə taɪɾ ə duəl, ən ðət ɹikwaɪɝd kɑm. "ɛvɹi mæn hɪɹ noʊz wɪv ənʌðɝ ɛnəmi tə ðə saʊθ," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə stɛɾi vɔɪs. "ðə sintʃæn əv swɑloʊd tæɹɑbən." hi ɹæn ɪz ɡeɪz oʊvɝ ðə tæɹɑbənɝz, ən mɛt flæt stɛɹz. hi nɛvɝ hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɹid tæɹɑbənɝz' feɪsəz.

Ituralde clasped his hands behind his back to keep from fingering the ruby in his left ear. That was widely known as a sign that lie was angry, and sometimes he did it on purpose, but he needed to present a calm face, now. Even while the man spoke past his ear! No. Calm. Duels were entered into in anger, but he was here to tight a duel, and that required calm. "Every man here knows we have another enemy to the south," he said in a steady voice. "The Seanchan have swallowed Tarabon." He ran his gaze over the Taraboners, and met flat stares. He never had been able to read Taraboners' faces.

bɪtwin ðoʊz pɹɪpɑstɝəs mʌstæʃɪz-laɪk hɛɹi tʌsks, wɝs ðən ə sɑldəiənz! -æn ðoʊz ɹɪdɪkjələs veɪlz, ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl wɛɹ mæsks, ən ðə pʊɹ laɪt fɹəm ðə læntɝnz dɪd nɑt hɛlp. bʌɾ i hæd sin əm veɪld ɪn meɪl, ən i niɾəd ðɛm. "ðeɪ hæv flʌɾəd ɑntu ɑlməθ pleɪn, ən muvd ɛvɝ nɔɹθ.

Between those preposterous mustaches-like hairy tusks, worse than a Saldaean's! -And those ridiculous veils, they might as well wear masks, and the poor light from the lanterns did not help. But he had seen them veiled in mail, and he needed them. "They have flooded onto Almoth Plain, and moved ever north.

ðɛɹ ɪntɛn ɪz klɪɹ. ðeɪ min tə hæv ɑɹæd dumən, tu. ðeɪ min tə hæv ðə hoʊl wɝld, aɪ fɪɹ."

Their intent is clear. They mean to have Arad Doman, too. They mean to have the whole world, I fear."

"dʌz lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi wɑnə noʊ hu wɪl səpɔɹɾ ɪf ðiz sintʃæn ɪnveɪɾ ʌs." weɪkeɪɾə dɪmændəd.

"Does Lord Ituralde want to know who we will support if these Seanchan invade us." Wakeda demanded.

"aɪ hæv tʃɹu feɪθ jəl faɪt fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən, lɔɹd weɪkeɪɾə," ɪɾɝɑldi sɛd maɪldli. weɪkeɪɾə wɛn pɝpəl ət hævɪŋ ðə dɝɛkt ɪnsəl flʌŋ ɪn ɪz tiθ, ən ɪz oʊθ-mɛnz hænz wɛn tə hɪls.

"I have true faith you will fight for Arad Doman, Lord Wakeda," Ituralde said mildly. Wakeda went purple at having the direct insult flung in his teeth, and his oath-men's hands went to hilts.

"ɹɛfjudʒiz əv bɹɔt wɝd ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ il ɑn ðə pleɪn, naʊ," ʃɪmɹɑn pʊɾ ɪn kwɪkli, əz ðoʊ hi fɪɹd weɪkeɪɾə maɪt bɹeɪk ðə waɪt ɹɪbən. nʌn ʌv weɪkeɪɾəz oʊθ-mɛn wəd dʒɹɔ stil ənlɛs i dɪd, əɹ kəmændəɾ əm tə, "ðeɪ faɪt fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, soʊ seɪ ðə ɹɪpɔɹts. hi mʌst əv sɛn ðɛm, pɝhæps əz ən eɪd tə ʌs. noʊ wʌn əz ɛvɝ dɪfiɾəd ən il ɑɹmi, nɑɾ ivən ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. jə ɹikɔl ðə blʌd snoʊ, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi, wən wi wɝ jʌŋɡɝ? aɪ bɪliv jə əɡɹi wɪð mi ðət wi dɪd nɑt dɪfiɾ əm ðɛɹ, wʌtɛvɝ ðə hɪstɝiz meɪ seɪ ən aɪ kænɑt bɪliv ðə sintʃæn əv ðə nʌmbɝz wi dɪd ðɛn. aɪ maɪsɛlf əv hɝɾ ə sintʃæn muvɪŋ saʊθ, əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝ.

"Refugees have brought word that there are Aiel on the plain, now," Shimron put in quickly, as though he feared Wakeda might break the White Ribbon. None of Wakeda's oath-men would draw steel unless he did, or commanded them to, "They fight for the Dragon Reborn, so say the reports. He must have sent them, perhaps as an aid to us. No one has ever defeated an Aiel army, not even Artur Hawkwing. You recall the Blood Snow, Lord Ituralde, when we were younger? I believe you agree with me that we did not defeat them there, whatever the histories may say and I cannot believe the Seanchan have the numbers we did then. I myself have heard of Seanchan moving south, away from the border.

noʊ, aɪ səspɛk ðə nɛkst wi hɪɹ wɪl bi ʌv əm ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə pleɪn, nɑɾ ədvænsɪŋ ɑn ʌs." hi wɑz nɑɾ ə bæd kəmændɝ ɪn ðə fild, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn pədæntɪk.

No, I suspect the next we hear will be of them retreating from the plain, not advancing on us." He was not a bad commander in the field, but he had always been pedantic.

ɪɾɝɑldi smaɪld. wɝd keɪm mɔɹ swɪfli fɹəm ðə saʊθ ðən fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn əfɹeɪɾ i wəɾ əv tə bɹɪŋ ʌp ði il, ən ðeɪ maɪɾ əv θɔɾ i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃɹɪk ðɛm.

Ituralde smiled. Word came more swiftly from the south than from anywhere else, but he had been afraid he would have to bring up the Aiel, and they might have thought he was trying to trick them.

hi kəd hɑɹdli bɪliv ɪt hɪmsɛlf, il ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn. hi dɪd nɑt pɔɪn aʊt ðəɾ il sɛn tə hɛlp ðə dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn wɝ mɔɹ laɪkli tə hæv əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ɪtsɛlf." aɪv kwɛstʃən ɹɛfjudʒiz, tu, ən ðeɪ spik ʌv il ɹeɪdz, nɑɾ ɑɹmiz. wʌtɛvɝ ði il ɑɹ duɪŋ ɑn ðə pleɪn meɪ hæv sloʊd ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ ɪt hæzən tɝn əm bæk. ðɛɹ flaɪɪŋ bists əv bɪɡʌn skaʊɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ saɪɾ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝ. ðət dʌz nɑt smæk ə ɹitʃɹit."

He could hardly believe it himself, Aiel on Almoth Plain. He did not point out that Aiel sent to help the Dragonsworn were more likely to have appeared in Arad Doman itself." I've questioned refugees, too, and they speak of Aiel raids, not armies. Whatever the Aiel are doing on the plain may have slowed the Seanchan, but it hasn't turned them back. Their flying beasts have begun scouting on our side of the border. That does not smack of retreat."

pɹədusɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ fɹəm ɪz sliv wɪð ə flɝɪʃ, hi hɛld ɪɾ ʌp soʊ ɔl kəd si ðə sɔɹɾ ən hæn ɪmpɹɛst ɪn ɡɹin-ænd-blu wæks. əz ɔlweɪz ə leɪt, hi hæd juzd ə hɑt bleɪd tə sɛpɝeɪt ðə ɹɔɪəl sil ɑn wʌn saɪd waɪl livɪŋ ɪt hoʊl, soʊ hi kəd ʃoʊ ɪɾ ənbɹoʊkən tə daʊɾɝz. ðəɹ hæd bɪn plɛnti ʌv ðoʊz, wən ðeɪ hɝd səm ʌv ælsələmz ɔɹɾɝz-"aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm kɪŋ ælsələm tə ɡæðɝ əz mɛni mɛn əz aɪ kæn, fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ aɪ kən faɪn ðɛm, ən stʃɹaɪk əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪ kən ət ðə sintʃæn." hi tʊk ə dip bɹitʃ. hɪɹ, hi tʊk ənʌðɝ tʃæns-æn ælsələm maɪɾ əv ɪz hɛɾ ɑn daɪ blɑk ənlɛs ðə daɪs fɛl ðə ɹaɪt weɪ. "aɪ ɔfɝ ə tʃɹus-aɪ plɛdʒ ɪn ðə kɪŋz neɪm nɑt tə muv əɡɛns jə ɪn ɛni weɪ soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə sintʃæn ɹɪmeɪn ə θɹɛt tə ɑɹæd dumən, ɪf jəl ɔl plɛdʒ ðə seɪm ən faɪt bɪsaɪd mi əɡɛnst əm əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ biɾən bæk." ə stʌn saɪləns ænsɝd hɪm. bʊl-nɛkt ɹədʒɑbi əpɪɹd pɑliækst. weɪkeɪɾə tʃuɾ ɪz lɪp laɪk ə stɑɹɾəld ɡɝl ðən ʃɪmɹɑn mʌɾɝd, "kæn ðeɪ bi biɾən bæk, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi? aɪ feɪs ðɛɹ . . . ðɛɹ tʃeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn, əz dɪd ju." buts skɹeɪp ðə flɔɹ əz mɛn ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ fiɾ ən feɪsəz dɑɹkən ɪn blik æŋɡɝ. noʊ mæn laɪk tə θɪŋk i wɑz hɛlpləs bɪfɔɹ ən ɛnəmi, bʌɾ ɪnʌf hæd bɪn ðəɹ ɪn ði ɝli deɪz, wɪð ɪɾɝɑldi ən ʃɪmɹɑn, fəɹ ɔl tə noʊ wʌt ðɪs ɛnəmi wɑz laɪk.

Producing the paper from his sleeve with a flourish, he held it up so all could see the Sword and Hand impressed in green-and-blue wax. As always of late, he had used a hot blade to separate the Royal Seal on one side while leaving it whole, so he could show it unbroken to doubters. There had been plenty of those, when they heard some of Alsalam's orders-"I have orders from King Alsalam to gather as many men as I can, from wherever I can find them, and strike as hard as I can at the Seanchan." He took a deep breach. Here, he took another chance-and Alsalam might have his head on die block unless the dice fell the right way. "I offer a truce-I pledge in the King's name not to move against you in any way so long as the Seanchan remain a threat to Arad Doman, if you will all pledge the same and fight beside me against them until they are beaten back." A stunned silence answered him. Bull-necked Rajabi appeared poleaxed. Wakeda chewed his lip like a startled girl Then Shimron muttered, "Can they be beaten back, Lord Ituralde? I faced their . . . their chained Aes Sedai on Almoth Plain, as did you." Boots scraped the floor as men shifted their feet and faces darkened in bleak anger. No man liked to think he was helpless before an enemy, but enough had been there in the early days, with Ituralde and Shimron, for all to know what this enemy was like.

"ðeɪ kən bi dɪfiɾəd. lɔɹd ʃɪmɹɑn," ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪplaɪd, "ivən wɪð ðɛɹ . . . lɪɾəl sɝpɹaɪzəz." ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋ tə kɔl ði ɝθ ɪɹʌptɪŋ ʌndɝ jəɹ fit, ən skaʊts ðət ɹoʊd wʌt lʊk laɪk ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, bʌɾ i hæd tə saʊn əʃʊɹɾ əz wɛl əz lʊk ɪt. bɪsaɪdz, wən jə nu wʌt ði ɛnəmi kʊd, du, jə ədæptəd. ðət hæd bɪn wʌn kɔɹ ʌv wɔɹfɛɹ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə sintʃæn əpɪɹd. dɑɹknəs kʌt ðə sintʃæn ædvæntɪdʒɪz, ən soʊ dɪd stɔɹmz, ən ə wɛðɝ-waɪz kəɾ ɔlweɪz tɛl jɑn wən ə stɔɹm wɑz kʌmɪŋ. "ə waɪz mæn stɑps tʃuɪŋ wən i ɹitʃəz boʊn," hi kəntɪnjud, "bʌt soʊ fɑɹ, ðə sintʃæn əv hæd ðɛɹ mit slaɪs θɪn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪt. aɪ ɪntɛn tə ɡɪv əm ə tʌf ɹoʊs tə nɔ. mɔɹ, aɪ hæv ə plæn tə meɪk əm snæp soʊ hɑɹd ðəl bɹeɪk ðɛɹ tiθ ɑn boʊn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪv ə maʊθfʊl ə mit. naʊ. aɪ hæv plɛdʒd. wɪl ju?"

"They can be defeated. Lord Shimron," Ituralde replied, "even with their . . . little surprises." A strange thing to call the earth erupting under your feet, and scouts that rode what looked like Shadowspawn, but he had to sound assured as well as look it. Besides, when you knew what the enemy could, do, you adapted. That had been one core of warfare long before the Seanchan appeared. Darkness cut the Seanchan advantages, and so did storms, and a weather-wise could always tell yon when a storm was coming. "A wise man stops chewing when he reaches bone," he continued, "but so far, the Seanchan have had their meat sliced thin before they reached for it. I intend to give them a tough roast to gnaw. More, I have a plan to make them snap so hard they'll break their teeth on bone before they have a mouthful of meat. Now. I have pledged. Will you?"

ɪt wɑz hɑɹd nɔɹ tə hoʊld ɪz bɹɛθ. itʃ mæn sim tə bi lʊkɪŋ ɪnwɝd. hi kəɾ ɔl bʌtsi ðɛm mʌlɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ. ðə wʊlf hæɾ ə plæn. ðə sintʃæn hæd tʃeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ ən flaɪɪŋ bists ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɛls. bʌt ðə wʊlf hæɾ ə plæn. ðə sintʃæn. ðə wʊlf. "ɪf ɛni mæn kən dɪfit ðɛm," ʃɪmɹɑn sɛd faɪnəli "ju kæn, lɔɹɾ ɪɾɝɑldi. əl soʊ plɛdʒ."

It was hard nor to hold his breath. Each man seemed to be looking inward. He could all butsee them mulling it over. The Wolf had a plan. The Seanchan had chained Aes Sedai and flying beasts and the Light alone knew what else. But the Wolf had a plan. The Seanchan. The Wolf. "If any man can defeat them," Shimron said finally "you can, Lord Ituralde. I will so pledge."

"aɪ də soʊ plɛdʒ!" ɹədʒɑbi ʃaʊɾəd. "wil tʃeɪs əm bæk əkɹɔs ði oʊʃən wɛɹ ðeɪ keɪm fɹʌm!" hi hæɾ ə bʊlz tɛmpɹəmən əz wɛl əz ɪts nɛk.

"I do so pledge!" Rajabi shouted. "We'll chase them back across the ocean where they came from!" He had a bull's temperament as well as its neck.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli weɪkeɪɾə θʌndɝɾ ɪz əɡɹimənt wɪð ikwəl ɪnθuziæzəm, ən ðən ə stɔɹm ə vɔɪsəz bɹoʊk, kɔlɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wəd mætʃ ðə kɪŋz plɛdʒ, ðət ðeɪ wəd smæʃ ðə sintʃæn, ivən səm ðət wəd fɑloʊ ðə wʊlf ɪndə ðə pɪɾ ə dum. ɔl vɛɹi ɡɹæɾəfaɪɪŋ bʌt nɑɾ ɔl ɪɾɝɑldi hæd kʌm fɔɹ.

Surprisingly Wakeda thundered his agreement with equal enthusiasm, and then a storm of voices broke, calling that they would match the King's pledge, that they would smash the Seanchan, even some that would follow the Wolf into the Pit of Doom. All very gratifying but not all Ituralde had come for.

"ɪf jə æsk əs tə faɪt fəɹ ɑɹæd dumən," wʌn vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd əbʌv ðə ɹɛst, "ðɛn æsk ʌs!" ðə mɛn u hæd bɪn kɔlɪŋ ðɛɹ plɛdʒɪz fɛl tə æŋɡɹi mʌɾɝz ən hæf-hɝd kɝsɪz.

"If you ask us to fight for Arad Doman," one voice shouted above the rest, "then ask us!" The men who had been calling their pledges fell to angry mutters and half-heard curses.

haɪɾɪŋ ɪz plɛʒɝ bɪhaɪn ə blæn ɪkspɹɛʃən, ɪɾɝɑldi tɝn tə feɪs ðə spikɝ, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wɑz ə lin mæn, wɪð ə ʃɑɹp noʊz ðət meɪɾ ə tɛn ə hɪz veɪl. hɪz aɪz wɝ hɑɹd, ðoʊ, ən kin. səm ə ði ʌðɝ tæɹɑbənɝz fɹaʊn əz ɪf dɪsplizd i hæd spoʊkən, soʊ ɪɾ əpɪɹd ðeɪ hæd noʊ wʌn liɾɝ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə dəmɑni, bʌɾ i hæd spoʊkən, ɪɾɝɑldi hæd hoʊp fəɹ ðə plɛdʒɪz i hæd ɹəsivd, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɔɹ nɛsəsɛɹi tə hɪz plæn. ðə tæɹɑbənɝz wɝ. ət list, ðeɪ wəd meɪk ɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz mɔɹ laɪkli tə wɝk. hi ədʒɹɛs ðə mæn kɔɝɾiəsli, wɪð ə baʊ.

Hiding his pleasure behind a bland expression, Ituralde turned to face the speaker, on the other side of the room, The Taraboner was a lean man, with a sharp nose that made a tent of his veil. His eyes were hard, though, and keen. Some of the other Taraboners frowned as if displeased he had spoken, so it appeared they had no one leader any more than the Domani, but he had spoken, Ituralde had hoped for the pledges he had received, but they were nor necessary to his plan. The Taraboners were. At least, they would make it a hundred times more likely to work. He addressed the man courteously, with a bow.

"aɪ ɔfɝ jə ðə tʃæns tə faɪt fəɹ tæɹɑbən, maɪ ɡʊd lɔɹd. ði il ɑɹ meɪkɪŋ səm kənfjuʒən ɑn ðə pleɪn; ðə ɹɛfjudʒiz spik ʌv ɪt. tɛl mi, kəɾ ə smɔl kʌmpəni ʌv jəɹ mɛn-ə hʌnʒɹəd, pɝhæps tu-kɹɔs ðə pleɪn ɪn ðət dɪsɔɹɾɝ ən ɛntɝ tæɹɑbən, ɪf ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ wɑz mɑɹkt wɪð stʃɹaɪps, əz ðoʊz u ɹaɪd fəɹ ðə sintʃæn."

"I offer you the chance to fight for Tarabon, my good Lord. The Aiel are making some confusion on the plain; the refugees speak of it. Tell me, could a small company of your men-a hundred, perhaps two-cross the plain in that disorder and enter Tarabon, if their armor was marked with stripes, as those who ride for the Seanchan."

ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðə tæɹɑbənɝz feɪs kəd ɡɹoʊ ɛni taɪɾɝ, jɛɾ ɪt dɪd, ən ɪt wɑz ðə tɝn ə ðə mɛn ɑn ɪz saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum tə mʌɾɝ æŋɡɹəli ən kɝs. ɪnʌf wɝd hæd kʌm nɔɹθ fəɹ əm tə noʊ ʌv ə kɪŋ ən pɑnɑɹtʃ pʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ θɹoʊnz baɪ ðə sintʃæn ən swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti tə ən ɛmpɹɛs ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðeɪ kəd nɑt laɪk ɹimaɪndɝz ə haʊ mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ kʌntʃɹimɪn naʊ ɹoʊd fəɹ ðɪs ɛmpɹɛs. moʊst ə ðə "sintʃæn" ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn wɝ tæɹɑbənɝz.

It seemed impossible the Taraboners face could grow any tighter, yet it did, and it was the turn of the men on his side of the room to mutter angrily and curse. Enough word had come north for them to know of a King and Panarch put on their thrones by the Seanchan and swearing fealty to an Empress on the other side of the Aryth Ocean. They could not like reminders of how many of their countrymen now rode for this Empress. Most of the "Seanchan" on Almoth Plain were Taraboners.

"wʌt ɡʊd kəd wʌn smɔl kʌmpəni du?" ðə lin mæn ɡɹaʊld, kəntɛmptʃuəs.

"What good could one small company do?" the lean man growled, contemptuous.

"lɪɾəl ɡʊd," ɪɾɝɑldi ɹɪplaɪd. "bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ fɪfti sətʃ kʌmpəniz? ə hʌnʒɹəd?" ðiz tæɹɑbənɝz maɪɾ əv ðət mɛni mɛn bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɔl toʊld. "ɪf ðeɪ ɔl stʃɹʌk ɑn ðə seɪm deɪ, ɔl əkɹɔs tæɹɑbən? aɪ maɪsɛlf wəd ɹaɪd wɪð ðɛm, ən əz mɛni ʌv maɪ mɛn əz kən bi aʊtfɪɾɪd ɪn tæɹɑbənɝ ɑɹmɝ. dʒʌst soʊ jəl noʊ ðɪs ɪz nɑt sɪmpli ə stʃɹæɾədʒɪm tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ju." bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə dəmɑni bɪɡæn pɹətɛstɪŋ laʊdli. weɪkeɪɾə ðə laʊɾəst ʌv ɔl, ɪf ɪt kəd bi bɪlivd! ðə wʊlfs plæn wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd ðə wʊlf hɪmsɛlf ət ðɛɹ hɛd. moʊst ə ðə tæɹɑbənɝz bɪɡæn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, oʊvɝ wɛðɝ soʊ mɛni mɛn kəd kɹɔs ðə pleɪn wɪθaʊt biɪŋ dɪskʌvɝd, ivən ɪn sətʃ smɔl bænz, oʊvɝ wʌt ɡʊd, ɪf ɛni, ðeɪ kəd də ɪn tæɹɑbən ɪn smɔl kʌmpəniz, oʊvɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə wɛɹ ɑɹmɝ mɑɹkt wɪð sintʃæn stʃɹaɪps. tæɹɑbənɝz ɑɹɡjuɾ əz izəli əz sɑldəiənz, ən əz hɑtli. nɑt ðə ʃɑɹp-noʊz mæn. hi mɛɾ ɪɾɝɑldiz ɡlɛɹ stɛɾəli.

"Little good," Ituralde replied. "But if there were fifty such companies? A hundred?" These Taraboners might have that many men behind them, all told. "If they all struck on the same day, all across Tarabon? I myself would ride with them, and as many of my men as can be outfitted in Taraboner armor. Just so you will know this is not simply a stratagem to get rid of you." Behind him, the Domani began protesting loudly. Wakeda the loudest of all, if it could be believed! The Wolf's plan was all very well, but they wanted the Wolf himself at their head. Most of the Taraboners began arguing among themselves, over whether so many men could cross the plain without being discovered, even in such small bands, over what good, if any, they could do in Tarabon in small companies, over whether they were willing to wear armor marked with Seanchan stripes. Taraboners argued as easily as Saldaeans, and as hotly. Not the sharp-nosed man. He met Ituralde's glare steadily.

ðən ɡeɪv ə slaɪt nɑd. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl, bɪhaɪn ðoʊz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz, bʌɾ ɪɾɝɑldi θɔɾ i smaɪld.

Then gave a slight nod. It was hard to tell, behind those thick mustaches, but Ituralde thought he smiled.

ðə læs tɛnʃən feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪɾɝɑldiz ʃoʊldɝz. ðə fɛloʊ wəd nɑɾ əv əɡɹid waɪl ði ʌðɝz ɑɹɡjuɾ ɪf i wɝ nɑt mɔɹ ʌv ə liɾɝ əmʌŋ əm ðən i simd. ði ʌðɝz wəd kʌm tu, hi wɑz sɝɾən. ðeɪ wəd ɹaɪd saʊθ wɪð ɪm ɪndə ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt ðə sintʃæn kənsɪɾɝd ðɛɹ oʊn, ən slæp əm hɑɹɾ ən fʊl əkɹɔs ðə feɪs. ðə tæɹɑbənɝz wəd wɑnə steɪ æftɝwɝdz, ʌv kɔɹs, ən kəntɪnju ðə faɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn hoʊmlænd. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ. wɪtʃ wəd liv ɪm ən ðə tu θaʊzən mɛn i kəd teɪk wɪð ɪm tə bi haʊndɪd bæk nɔɹθ əɡɛn, ɔl ðə lɔŋ weɪ əkɹɔs ɑlməθ pleɪn. ɪf ðə laɪt ʃoʊn ɑn hɪm, haʊndɪd wɪð fjʊɹi. hi ɹɪtɝn ðə tæɹɑbənɝz smaɪl, ɪf smaɪl ɪt wɑz. wɪð ɛni lʌk, fjʊɹiəs dʒɛnɝəlz wəd nɑt si wɛɹ i wɑz liɾɪŋ ðɛm, əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. ən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd... wɛl i hæɾ ə sɛkən plæn.

The last tension faded from Ituralde's shoulders. The fellow would not have agreed while the others argued if he were not more of a leader among them than he seemed. The others would come too, he was certain. They would ride south with him into the heart of what the Seanchan considered their own, and slap them hard and full across the face. The Taraboners would want to stay afterwards, of course, and continue the fight in their own homeland. He could not expect anything more. Which would leave him and the two thousand men he could take with him to be hounded back north again, all the long way across Almoth Plain. If the Light shone on him, hounded with fury. He returned the Taraboners smile, if smile it was. With any luck, furious generals would not see where he was leading them, until it was too late. And if they did... Well he had a second plan.

imən vɑldə hɛld ɪz kloʊk taɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf əz laɪ tʃɹæmp θɹu ðə snoʊ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz. koʊld ən stɛɾi, ðə wɪn saɪd θɹu ðə snoʊ-leɪɾən bɹæntʃəz, ə dɪsɛptɪvli kwaɪət saʊn ɪn ðə dæmp ɡɹeɪ laɪt. ɪt slaɪs θɹu ðə θɪk waɪt wʊl əz θɹu ɡɔz, tʃɪlɪŋ ɪm tə ðə boʊn. ðə kæmp spɹɔlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm θɹu ðə fɔɹəst wɑz tu kwaɪət. muvmən pɹəvaɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl wɔɹmθ, bʌɾ ɪn ðɪs, mɛn hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ ənlɛs dʒɹɪvən tə muv.

Eamon Valda held his cloak tight around himself as lie tramped through the snow among the trees. Cold and steady, the wind sighed through the snow-laden branches, a deceptively quiet sound in the damp gray light. It sliced through the thick white wool as through gauze, chilling him to the bone. The camp sprawling around him through the forest was too quiet. Movement provided a little warmth, but in this, men huddled together unless driven to move.

əbɹʌpli hi stɑpt ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks, ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ɪz noʊz əɾ ə sʌɾən stɛntʃ, ə ɡæɡɪŋ faʊlnəs laɪk twɛnti mɪɾən hips kɹɔlɪŋ wɪð mæɡəts. hi dɪd nɑt ɡæɡ; ɪnstɛd, hi skaʊld. ðə kæmp læk ðə pɹisɪʒən i pɹəfɝd. ðə tɛns wɝ klʌstɝd hæfəzɝdli wɛɹɛvɝ ðə lɪmz oʊvɝhɛd ɡɹu θɪkəst, ðə hɔɹsəz tɛðɝd kloʊs baɪ ɹæðɝ ðən pɹɑpɝli pɪkəɾɪd. ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə slæknəs ðət lɛd tə fɪlθ.

Abruptly he stopped in his tracks, wrinkling his nose at a sudden stench, a gagging foulness like twenty midden heaps crawling with maggots. He did not gag; instead, he scowled. The camp lacked the precision he preferred. The tents were clustered haphazardly wherever the limbs overhead grew thickest, the horses tethered close by rather than properly picketed. It was the sort of slackness that led to filth.

ənwɑtʃt, ðə mɛn wəd bɛɹi hɔɹs-dʌŋ ʌndɝ ə fju ʃʌvəlz ə dɝt tə bi dʌn wɪð ɪt kwɪkɝ, ən dɪɡ lætʃɹinz wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv tə wɔk fɑɹ ɪn ðə koʊld. ɛni ɔfəsɝ ə hɪz u əlaʊd ðət wəd sis tə bi ən ɔfəsɝ, ən lɝn fɝsthæn haʊ tə juz ə ʃʌvəl.

Unwatched, the men would bury horse-dung under a few shovels of dirt to be done with it quicker, and dig latrines where they would not have to walk far in the cold. Any officer of his who allowed that would cease to be an officer, and learn firsthand how to use a shovel.

hi wɑz skænɪŋ ðə kæmp fəɹ ðə sɔɹs ə ðə smɛl, wən sʌɾənli ðəɹ wɑz noʊ smɛl. ðə wɪn dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ; ðə stɪŋk dʒʌs vænɪʃt. hi wɑz stɑɹɾəld fəɹ oʊnli ə moʊmənt. wɔkɪŋ ɑn, hi skaʊld ɔl ðə hɑɹɾɝ. ðə stɛntʃ hæd kʌm fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ. hi wəd faɪn huɛvɝ θɔt dɪsəplən hæd slækənd, ən meɪk ɪɡzæmpəlz ə ðɛm. dɪsəplən hæd tə bi taɪt, naʊ; taɪɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ.

He was scanning the camp for the source of the smell, when suddenly there was no smell. The wind did not change; the stink just vanished. He was startled for only a moment. Walking on, he scowled all the harder. The stench had come from somewhere. He would find whoever thought discipline had slackened, and make examples of them. Discipline had to be tight, now; tighter than ever.

ət ði ɛdʒ ʌv əbɹɔd klɪɹɪŋ, hi pɔzd əɡɛn. ðə snoʊ ɪn ðə klɪɹɪŋ wɑz smuð ən ənmɑɹk dɪspaɪt ðə kæmp hɪɾən ɔl ɝaʊn ɪf. steɪdʒɪŋ bæk əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, laɪ skæn ðə skaɪ.

At the edge of abroad clearing, he paused again. The snow in the clearing was smooth and unmarked despite the camp hidden all around if. Staging back among the trees, lie scanned the sky.

skəɪŋ ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz hɪd ðə nundeɪ sʌn. ə flɪkɝ ə moʊʃən meɪɾ ɪz bɹɛθ kætʃ bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə bɝd, səm smɔl bɹaʊn θɪŋ wɛɹi ʌv hɔks ən steɪɪŋ loʊ. hi bɑɹkt .ə læf ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən tʌtʃt wɪð bɪɾɝnəs. lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə mʌnθ sɪns ðə laɪt-kɝst sintʃæn hæd swɑloʊɾ æmədɔɹ ən ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ə laɪɾ ɪn wʌn ʌnbəlivəbəl ɡʌlp, bʌɾ i hæd lɝnd nu ɪnstɪŋks.

Scudding gray clouds hid the noonday sun. A flicker of motion made his breath catch before he realized it was just a bird, some small brown thing wary of hawks and staying low. He barked .a laugh that was more than touched with bitterness. Little more than a month since the Light-cursed Seanchan had swallowed Amador and the Fortress of Light in one unbelievable gulp, but he had learned new instincts.

waɪz mɛn lɝnd, waɪl fulz ... eɪlɹən hæd bɪn ə ful pʌft ʌp wɪð oʊl teɪlz ʌv ɡlɔɹi bɹaɪɾənd baɪ eɪdʒ ən nu hoʊp ʌv wɪnɪŋ ɹil paʊɝ tə ɡoʊ wɪð ɪz kɹaʊn. hi ɹəfjuz tə si ðə ɹiæləɾi ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz, ən eɪlɹənz dɪzæstɝ hæd bɪn ðə ɹɪzʌlt. vɑldə hæd hɝɾ ɪt neɪm ðə bæɾəl ə dʒɹəməl, bʌɾ oʊnli baɪ səm ə ðə bɛɹ hændfʊl ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃən noʊbəlz u ɪskeɪpt, deɪzd əz pɑliækst stɪɹz jɛt stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ məkænɪkli tə pʊt ðə bɛs feɪs ɑn ɪvɛns. hi wʌndɝd wʌɾ eɪlɹən hæd kɔld ɪt wən ðə sintʃænz teɪm wɪtʃəz bɪɡæn tɛɹɪŋ ɪz ɔɹɾɝli ɹæŋks tə blʌɾi ɹæɡz. hi kəd stɪl si ðəɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ði ɝθ tɝnɪŋ tə faʊntənz ə faɪɝ. hi sɔ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz-wɛl, eɪlɹən wɑz dɛd, kʌt daʊn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fli ðə fild ən ɪz hɛd dɪspleɪst ɑn ə tæɹɑbənɝz læns. ə suɾəbəl dɛθ fəɹ ə ful. hi, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hæɾ oʊvɝ naɪn θaʊzən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. ə mæn u sɔ klɪɹli kəd meɪk mʌtʃ aʊɾ ə ðəɾ ɪn taɪmz laɪk ðiz.

Wise men learned, while fools ... Ailron had been a fool puffed up with old tales of glory brightened by age and new hope of winning real power to go with his crown. He refused to see the reality in front of his eyes, and Ailron's Disaster had been the result. Valda had heard it named the Battle of Jeramel, but only by some of the bare handful of Amadician nobles who escaped, dazed as poleaxed steers yet still trying mechanically to put the best face on events. He wondered what Ailron had called it when the Seanchan's tame witches began tearing his orderly ranks to bloody rags. He could still see that in his head, the earth turning to fountains of fire. He saw it in his dreams-Well, Ailron was dead, cut down trying to flee the field and his head displaced on a Taraboner's lance. A suitable death for a fool. He, on the other hand, had over nine thousand of the Children gathered around him. A man who saw clearly could make much out of that in times like these.

ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə tʃɹilaɪn, wɑz ə ɹud haʊs ðət hæd wʌns bɪlɔŋ tə ə tʃɑɹkoʊl bɝnɝ, ə sɪŋɡəl ɹum wɪð wɪntɝ-bɹɔn widz θɪk ɪn ðə ɡæps bɪtwin ðə stoʊnz. baɪ ɔl əpɪɹənsəz, ðə mæn hæɾ əbændən ðə pleɪs səm taɪm əɡoʊ; pɑɹts ə ðə θætʃ ɹuf sæɡd deɪnʒɝəsli, ən wʌtɛvɝ hæd wʌns fɪl ðə nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊz wɑz lɔŋ sɪns ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs naʊ baɪ dɑɹk blæŋkəts. tu ɡɑɹdz stʊd bɪsaɪd ði ɪl-fɪɾɪŋ wʊɾən dɔɹ-bɪɡ mɛn wɪð ðə skɑɹlət ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk bɪhaɪn ðə ɡoʊldən sʌnflɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks. ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛmsɛlvz ən wɝ stæmpɪŋ ðɛɹ buts əɡɛns ðə koʊld. niðɝ cʊɾə ɹitʃt ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn taɪm tə də ɛni ɡʊd, hæd vɑldə bɪn ən ɛnəmi. kwɛstʃənɝz laɪk tə wɝk ɪndɔɹz.

On the far side of the clearing, just inside the treeline, was a rude house that had once belonged to a charcoal burner, a single room with winter-brawn weeds thick in the gaps between the stones. By all appearances, the man had abandoned the place some time ago; parts of the thatch roof sagged dangerously, and whatever had once filled the narrow windows was long since gone, replaced now by dark blankets. Two guards stood beside the ill-fitting wooden door-big men with the scarlet shepherd's crook behind the golden sunflare on their cloaks. They had their arms wrapped around themselves and were stamping their boots against the cold. Neither could have reached his sword in time to do any good, had Valda been an enemy. Questioners liked to work indoors.

ðɛɹ feɪsəz maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹv stoʊn əz ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɪm əpɹoʊtʃ. niðɝ ɔfɝd mɔɹ ðən ə hæfhɑɹɾɪd səlut. nɑt fəɹ ə mæn wɪθaʊt ðə ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk, ivən ɪf i wɑz lɔɹd-kæptən kəmændɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. wʌn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əz ɪf tə kwɛstʃən vɑldəz pɝpəs, bʌt vɑldə wɔk baɪ ðɛm ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə ɹʌf dɔɹ. ət lis ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɪm. hi wʊɾə kɪld əm boʊθ, ɪf ðeɪ hæd.

Their faces might have been carved stone as they watched him approach. Neither offered more than a halfhearted salute. Not for a man without the shepherd's crook, even if he was Lord-Captain Commander of the Children. One opened his mouth as if to question Valda's purpose, but Valda walked by them and pushed open the rough door. At least they did not try to stop him. He would have killed them both, if they had.

əɾ ɪz ɛntʃɹəns, əsunɑwə lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə kɹʊkəd teɪbəl wɛɹ i wɑz pɝuzɪŋ ə smɔl bʊk, wʌn boʊni hæn kʌpt ɝaʊn ə stimɪŋ pjuɾɝ kʌp ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ði oʊɾɝ ə spaɪsəz. hɪz læɾɝ-bækt tʃɛɹ, ði oʊnli ʌðɝ pis ə fɝnɪtʃɝ ɪn ðə ɹum, əpɪɹd ɹɪkəɾi, bʌt sʌmwʌn hæd stʃɹɛŋθən ɪt wɪð ɹɔhaɪd læʃɪŋz. vɑldə taɪɾənd ɪz maʊθ tə stɑp ə snɪɹ. ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ ə ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt dɪmændəɾ ə ɹil ɹuf, nɑɾ ə tɛnt, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz θætʃ sɔɹli ɪn niɾ ə pætʃɪŋ, ən mʌld waɪn wən noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd teɪstəd, waɪn ʌv ɛni sɔɹɾ ɪn ə wik. ə smɔl faɪɝ bɝn ɑn ðə stoʊn hɑɹθ, tu, ɡɪvɪŋ ə miɡɝ wɔɹmθ. ivən kʊk faɪɝz hæd bɪn bæn sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə dɪzæstɝ, tə pɹɪvɛn smoʊk fɹəm ɡɪvɪŋ əm əweɪ. stɪl, ɔlðoʊ moʊs tʃɪlʒɹən dɪspaɪz ðə kwɛstʃənɝz, ðeɪ hɛld əsunɑwə ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪstim, əz ɪf ɪz ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ən ɡɔn mɑɹɾɝz feɪs ɡɹeɪst ɪm wɪð ɔl ði aɪdilz ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðət hæd bɪn ə sɝpɹaɪz, wən vɑldə fɝs lɝn ʌv ɪt; hi wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɛðɝ əsunɑwə hɪmsɛlf nu. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf kwɛstʃənɝz tə meɪk tʃɹʌbəl. nʌθɪŋ i kəd nɑt hændəl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛs tə əvɔɪd ðət sɔɹɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl. fəɹ naʊ.

At his entrance, Asunawa looked up from the crooked table where he was perusing a small book, one bony hand cupped around a steaming pewter cup that gave off the odor of spices. His ladder-backed chair, the only other piece of furniture in the room, appeared rickety, but someone had strengthened it with rawhide lashings. Valda tightened his mouth to stop a sneer. The High Inquisitor of the Hand of the Light demanded a real roof, not a tent, even if it was thatch sorely in need of patching, and mulled wine when no one else had tasted, wine of any sort in a week. A small fire burned on the stone hearth, too, giving a meager warmth. Even cook fires had been banned since before the Disaster, to prevent smoke from giving them away. Still, although most Children despised the Questioners, they held Asunawa in a strange esteem, as if his gray hair and gaunt martyr's face graced him with all the ideals of the Children of the Light. That had been a surprise, when Valda first learned of it; he was unsure whether Asunawa himself knew. In any case, there were enough Questioners to make trouble. Nothing he could not handle, but it was best to avoid that sort of trouble. For now.

"ɪɾ ɪz ɔlmoʊs taɪm," hi sɛd, ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi?" əsunɑwə meɪd noʊ muv tə ɹaɪz əɹ ɹitʃ fəɹ ðə waɪt kloʊk foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"It is almost time," he said, shutting the door behind him. "Are you ready?" Asunawa made no move to rise or reach for the white cloak folded across the table beside him.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sʌn-flɛɹ ɑn ðæt, dʒʌs ðə skɑɹlət kɹʊk. ɪnstɛd, hi foʊldəɾ ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ðə bʊk, haɪɾɪŋ ðə peɪdʒəz. vɑldə θɔɾ ɪt wɑz mæntəlɝz ðə weɪ ʌv ðə laɪt. ɑd ɹɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ.

There was no sun-flare on that, just the scarlet crook. Instead, he folded his hands over the book, hiding the pages. Valda thought it was Mantelar's The Way of the Light. Odd reading for the High Inquisitor.

mɔɹ suɾəd tə nu ɹəkɹuts; ðoʊz u kəd nɑt ɹɛd wən ðeɪ swɔɹ wɝ tɔt soʊ ðət kəd stʌɾi mæntəlɝz wɝdz. "aɪ hæv ɹɪpɔɹts ʌv ən ændɔɝən ɑɹmi ɪn mʊɹændi, maɪ sʌn," əsunɑwə sɛd. "dip ɪn mʊɹændi, pɝhæps."

More suited to new recruits; those who could not read when they swore were taught so that could study Mantelar's words. "I have reports of an Andoran army in Murandy, my son," Asunawa said. "Deep in Murandy, perhaps."

"mʊɹændi ɪz ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm hɪɹ," vɑldə sɛɾ əz ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ən oʊld ɑɹɡjəmən stɑɹɾɪŋ ənu. ən ɑɹɡjəmən ðəɾ əsunɑwə ɔfən sim tə fɝɡɛɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɔst. bʌt wʌt wɝ ændɔɹənz duɪŋ ɪn mʊɹændi? ɪf ðə ɹɪpɔɹts wɝ tʃɹu; soʊ mɛni wɝ tʃɹævəlɝz fæntəsiz ɹæpt ɪn laɪz.

"Murandy is a long way from here," Valda said as though he did not recognize an old argument starting anew. An argument that Asunawa often seemed to forget he had already lost. But what were Andorans doing in Murandy? If the reports were true; so many were travelers fantasies wrapped in lies.

ændɝ. ðə vɛɹi neɪm ɹæŋkəld ɪn vɑldəz mɛmɹi. mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz dɛd, əɹ ɛls ə sɝvən tə səm sintʃæn. ðeɪ hæd lɪɾəl ɹɪspɛk fəɹ taɪɾəlz ʌðɝ ðən ðɛɹ oʊn. dɛɾ əɹ ə sɝvənt, ʃi wɑz lɔs tə hɪm, ən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli baɪ fɑɹ, hɪz plænz fəɹ ændɝ wɝ lɔst. ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd hæd ɡɔn fɹəm ə jusfəl lɛvɝ tə dʒʌst ənʌðɝ jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ, ən wʌn u wɑz tu pɑpjəlɝ wɪð ðə kɑmən soʊlʒɝz. ɡʊɾ ɔfəsɝz wɝ nɛvɝ pɑpjəlɝ. bʌt vɑldə wɑz ə pɹæɡmæɾɪk mæn. ðə pæst wɑz ðə pæst. nu plænz hæd ɹipleɪst ændɝ.

Andor. The very name rankled in Valda's memory. Morgase was dead, or else a servant to some Seanchan. They had little respect for titles other than their own. Dead or a servant, she was lost to him, and more importantly by far, his plans for Andor were lost. Galadedrid had gone from a useful lever to just another young officer, and one who was too popular with the common soldiers. Good officers were never popular. But Valda was a pragmatic man. The past was the past. New plans had replaced Andor.

"nɔɹ soʊ fɑɹ ɪf wi muv ist, əkɹɔs ɔltɑɹə maɪ sʌn, əkɹɔs ðə nɔɹθ ʌv ɔltɑɹə. ðə sintʃæn kænɑɾ əv muv fɑɹ fɹəm ɛbən dɑɹ jɛt.

"Nor so far if we move east, across Altara my son, across the north of Altara. The Seanchan cannot have moved far from Ebon Dar yet.

spɹɛɾɪŋ ɪz hænz tə kætʃ ðə hɑɹθfaɪɝz smɔl wɔɹmθ, vɑldə saɪd. ðeɪ hæɾ ədvæns laɪk ə pleɪɡ ɪn tæɹɑbən, ən hɪɹ ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə. waɪ dɪd ðə mæn θɪŋk ɔltɑɹə wɑz dɪfɹənt? ɑɹ jə fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðə wɪtʃəz ɪn ɔltɑɹə? wɪð ən ɑɹmi ʌv ðɛɹ oʊn, niɾ aɪ ɹimaɪn ju? ənlɛs ðəɹ ɪndə mʊɹændi baɪ naʊ." ðoʊz ɹɪpɔɹts i bɪlivd, ʌv ðə wɪtʃəz ɑn ðə muv. ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf, hɪz vɔɪs ɹoʊz. "meɪbi ðɪs soʊ-kɔld ændɔɝən ɑɹmi juv hɝɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz ðə wɪtʃəz, ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmi! ðeɪ ɡeɪv keɪɛmlɪn tə ælθɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ! ən ɪljən, ən hæf ði ist. dʒju ɹɪli bɪliv ðə wɪtʃəz ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd? də ju!" sloʊli hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, kɑmɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə. ɛvɹi teɪl aʊɾ ə ði ist wɑz wɝs ðən ðə læst. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn daʊn ðə tʃɪmni blu spɑɹks ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən i stɛp bæk wɪð ə kɝs. blʌɾi pɛzən hʌvəl! ivən ðə tʃɪmni wɑz ɪl-meɪd!

Spreading his hands to catch the hearthfire's small warmth, Valda sighed. They had advanced like a plague in Tarabon, and here in Amadicia. Why did the man think Altara was different? Are you forgetting the witches in Altara? With an army of their own, need I remind you? Unless they're into Murandy by now." Those reports he believed, of the witches on the move. In spite of himself, his voice rose. "Maybe this so-called Andoran army you've heard about is the witches, and their army! They gave Caemlyn to al'Thor, remember! And Illian, and half the east. Do you really believe the witches are divided? Do you!" Slowly he drew a deep breath, calming himself. Trying to. Every tale out of the east was worse than the last. A gust of wind down the chimney blew sparks into the room, and he stepped back with a curse. Bloody peasant hovel! Even the chimney was ill-made!

əsunɑwə snæp ðə smɔl bʊk ʃʌt bɪtwin ɪz pɑmz. hɪz hænz wɝ foʊldəɾ əz ɪn pɹɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz sʌɾənli sim hɑɾɝ ðən ðə faɪɝ. "aɪ bɪliv ðə wɪtʃəz mʌs bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd!

Asunawa snapped the small book shut between his palms. His hands were folded as in prayer, but his deep-set eyes suddenly seemed hotter than the fire. "I believe the witches must be destroyed!

ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ bɪliv!"

That is what I believe!"

"aɪd sɛɾəl fəɹ noʊɪŋ haʊ ðə sintʃæn teɪm ðɛm." wɪð ɪnʌf feɪm wɪtʃəz, hi kəd dʒɹaɪv ælθɹ aʊɾ ʌv ændɝ, aʊɾ ʌv ɪljən ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɛls i hæd sɛɾəld laɪk ðə ʃædoʊ ɪtsɛlf. hi kəd bɛɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hɪmsɛlf!

"I'd settle for knowing how the Seanchan tame them." With enough fame witches, he could drive al'Thor out of Andor, out of Illian and everywhere else he had settled like the Shadow itself. He could better Hawkwing himself!

"ðeɪ mʌs bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd" əsunɑwə əsɝɾəd stʌbɝnli.

"They must be destroyed" Asunawa asserted stubbornly.

"æn əs wɪð ðɛm?" vɑldə dɪmændəd.

"And us with them?" Valda demanded.

ə nɑk keɪm ət ðə dɔɹ, ən əɾ əsunɑwəz kɝt sʌmənz wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹ-weɪ, stændɪŋ ɹɪdʒɪdli ɪɹɛkt, ɑɹm snæpɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ɪn ə kɹɪsp səlut. "maɪ lɔɹd haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ," hi sɛd ɹɪspɛkt-fʊli, "ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəɾ ɪz hɪɹ." vɑldə weɪɾəd. wəd ði oʊl ful kəntɪnju tə bi stʌbɝn wɪð ɔl tɛn sɝvaɪvɪŋ lɔɹdz kæptən aʊtsaɪd, maʊntəɾ ən ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪd? wʌt wɑz dʌn, wɑz dʌn. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn.

A knock came at the door, and at Asunawa's curt summons one of the guards from outside appeared in the door-way, standing rigidly erect, arm snapping across his chest in a crisp salute. "My Lord High Inquisitor," he said respect-fully, "the Council of the Anointed is here." Valda waited. Would the old fool continue to be stubborn with all ten surviving Lords Captain outside, mounted and ready to ride? What was done, was done. What had to be done.

"ɪf ɪt bɹɪŋz daʊn ðə waɪt taʊɝ," əsunɑwə sɛd faɪnəli, "aɪ kən bi kəntɛnt. fəɹ naʊ. əl kʌm tə ðɪs miɾɪŋ."

"If it brings down the White Tower," Asunawa said finally, "I can be content. For now. I will come to this meeting."

vɑldə smaɪl θɪnli. "ðɛn aɪm kɑntɛnt. wɪl si ðə wɪtʃəz feɪl təɡɛðɝ." sɝɾənli, hi wəd si ðɛm fɔl, "aɪ sədʒɛs juv jəɹ hɔɹs ɹɛɾid. wɪv ə lɔŋ weɪ tə ɹaɪd baɪ naɪtfɔl." wɛðɝ əsunɑwə wəd si ɪt wɪð ɪm wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

Valda smiled thinly. "Then I am content. We will see the witches fail together." Certainly, he would see them fall, "I suggest you have your horse readied. We have a long way to ride by nightfall." Whether Asunawa would see it with him was another matter.

ɡɑbɹɛl ɛndʒɔɪɾ əɹ ɹaɪdz θɹu ðə wɪntʃɹi wʊdz wɪð lɑɡən ən tʌvaɪn. hi ɔlweɪz lɛt tʌvaɪn ən əɹ fɑloʊ ət ðɛɹ oʊn peɪs ɪn ə sɛmbləns ə pɹaɪvəsi, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt læɡ tu fɑɹ bɪhaɪnd.

Gabrelle enjoyed her rides through the wintry woods with Logain and Toveine. He always let Toveine and her follow at their own pace in a semblance of privacy, so long as they did not lag too far behind.

ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛldəm spoʊk mɔɹ ðən æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi ðoʊ, ivən wən ðeɪ tʃɹuli wɝ pɹaɪvət. ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ fɹəm fɹɛnz. ɪn fækt, ɡɑbɹɛl ɔfən wɪʃt tʌvaɪn wəɾ æsk tə steɪ bɪhaɪnd wən lɑɡən ɔfɝd ðiz aʊɾɪŋz. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn vɛɹi plɛzən tə bi ɹɪli əloʊn.

The two Aes Sedai seldom spoke more than absolutely necessary though, even when they truly were private. They were far from friends. In fact, Gabrelle often wished Toveine would ask to stay behind when Logain offered these outings. It would have been very pleasant to be really alone.

hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz ɪn wʌn ɡɹin-ɡlʌv hæn ən kipɪŋ əɹ fɑks-laɪn kloʊk ʃʌt wɪð ði ʌðɝ, ʃi lɛt hɝsɛlf fil ðə koʊld, dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl, fɝs fəɹ ðə ɹɪfɹɛʃɪŋ vɪɡɝ ʌv ɪt. ðə snoʊ wɑz nɑt dip, bʌt ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɛɹ wɑz kɹɪsp. dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz pɹɑməs mɔɹ snoʊ, sun. haɪ oʊvɝhɛd flu ə lɔŋ-wɪndɪd bɝɾ ə səm sɔɹt. ən iɡəl, pɝhæps; bɝdz wɝ nɑɾ əɹ stʃɹɔŋ pɔɪnt. plæns ən mɪnɝəlz steɪɾ ɪn wʌn pleɪs waɪl jə stʌɾid ðɛm, ən soʊ dɪd bʊks ən mænjəskɹɪps, ðoʊ ðoʊz maɪt kɹʌmbəl ʌndɝ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ oʊld ɪnʌf. ʃi kəd bɛɹli meɪk ðə bɝɾ aʊɾ ət ðət haɪt, ɪn ɛni keɪs, bʌɾ ən iɡəl fɪt ðə lændskeɪp-wʊdlæn sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, smɔl dɛns θɪkəts dɑɾəd əmʌŋ mɔɹ waɪdli speɪs tʃɹiz. ɡɹeɪɾ oʊks ən taʊɝɪŋ paɪnz ən fɹz hæd kɪld ə moʊst ə ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ, ðoʊ hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ðə θɪk bɹaʊn ɹɪmeɪnz ʌv ə hɑɹɾi vaɪn, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə stɪl dɪstən spɹɪŋ, klʌŋ tə ə boʊldɝ əɹ ə loʊ ɡɹeɪ lɛdʒ ə stoʊn. ʃi kɛɹfəli hɛl ðət lændskeɪp ɪn əɹ maɪn laɪk ə nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪz, tʃɪl ən ɛmpti. wɪð noʊ wʌn ɪn saɪɾ ɪksɛpt əɹ tu kəmpænjənz, ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmædʒən ʃi wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ʌðɝ ðən ðə blæk taʊɝ. ðət hɔɹəd neɪm keɪm ɔl tu izəli tə maɪnd, naʊ. ə θɪŋ əz ɹil əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ "soʊ-kɔld" fəɹ ɛniwʌn u leɪɾ aɪz ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt stoʊn bæɹəks, bɪldɪŋz ðət hɛl hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, ən ðə vɪlədʒ ðət hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp ɝaʊn ðɛm. ʃi hæd lɪvd ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ fəɹ nɪɹli tu wiks, ən ðəɹ wɝ pɑɹts ə ðə blæk taʊɝ ʃi stɪl hæd nɑt sin. ɪts ɡɹaʊnz kʌvɝd maɪlz, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋz ʌv ə wɔl ə blæk stoʊn. stɪl, ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɛt, hɪɹ ɪn ðə wʊdz.

Holding her reins in one green-gloved hand and keeping her fox-lined cloak shut with the other, she let herself feel the cold, just a little, first for the refreshing vigor of it. The snow was not deep, but the morning air was crisp. Dark gray clouds promised more snow, soon. High overhead flew a long-winded bird of some sort. An eagle, perhaps; birds were not her strong point. Plants and minerals stayed in one place while you studied them, and so did books and manuscripts, though those might crumble under her fingers, if they were old enough. She could barely make the bird out at that height, in any case, but an eagle fit the landscape-Woodland surrounded them, small dense thickets dotted among more widely spaced trees. Great oaks and towering pines and firs had killed of most of the undergrowth, though here and there the thick brown remains of a hardy vine, waiting for a still distant spring, clung to a boulder or a low gray ledge of stone. She carefully held that landscape in her mind like a novice exercise, chill and empty. With no one in sight except her two companions, she could almost imagine she was somewhere other than the Black Tower. That horrid name came all too easily to mind, now. A thing as real as the White Tower, and no longer "so-called" for anyone who laid eyes on the great stone barracks, buildings that held hundreds of men in training, and the village that had grown up around them. She had lived in that village for nearly two weeks, and there were parts of the Black Tower she still had not seen. Its grounds covered miles, surrounded by the beginnings of a wall of black stone. Still, she could almost forget, here in the woods.

ɔlmoʊst, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə bʌndəl ə sɛnseɪʃən ən ɪmoʊʃən, ði ɛsəns ə lɑɡən əblɝ, ðəɾ ɔlweɪz ɹoʊɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ maɪnd, ə kɑnstən fil ə kəntʃɹoʊld wɛɹinɪs, ʌv mʌsəlz ɔlweɪz ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə tɛnsɪŋ. ə hʌntɪŋ wʊlf maɪt fil ðət weɪ, əɹ pɝhæps ə laɪən. ðə mænz hɛd muv kɑnstənli; ivən hɪɹ i wɑtʃt ɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz əz ðoʊ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ətæk.

Almost, except for the bundle of sensation and emotion, the essence of Logain Ablar, that always rode in the back of her mind, a constant feel of controlled wariness, of muscles always on the edge of tensing. A hunting wolf might feel that way, or perhaps a lion. The man's head moved constantly; even here he watched his surroundings as though expecting attack.

ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hæɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ-ðeɪ wɝ nidləs flæmbɔɪəns fəɹ bɹaʊnz: ə haɪɝd sɝvən kəd də ɔl ʃi niɾəd-ænd ɪt fɛl pəkjuljɝ tə bi nɑɾ oʊnli pɑɹɾ ʌv ə bɑnd, bʌɾ ət ðə ɹɔŋ ɛn ʌv ɪt, soʊ tə spik.

She had never had a Warder-they were needless flamboyance for Browns: a hired servant could do all she needed-and it felt peculiar to be not only part of a bond, but at the wrong end of it, so to speak.

wɝs ðən sɪmpli ðə ɹɔŋ ɛnd; ðɪs bɑn ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə oʊbeɪ, ən ʃi wɑz hɛdʒd əbaʊt wɪð pɹoʊəbɪʃənz. soʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əz ə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd, ɹɪli. sɪstɝz dɪd nɑt fɔɹs ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz tə oʊbiɾiəns. wɛl, nɑt vɛɹi ɔfən. ən sɪstɝz hæd nɑt bɑndəd mɛn əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪl fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz. stɪl, ɪt dɪd pɹəvaɪɾ ə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ stʌɾi. ʃi hæd wɝkt əɾ ɪntɝpɹɛɾɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɛnst. ət taɪmz, ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɛɾ ɪz maɪnd. ʌðɝ taɪmz, ɪt wɑz laɪk fʌmbəlɪŋ θɹu ə maɪnʃæft wɪð noʊ læmp. ʃi səpoʊzd ʃi wəd tʃɹaɪ tə stʌɾi ɪf əɹ nɛk wɝ stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ðə hɛdzmənz blɑk. wɪtʃ, ɪn ə vɛɹi ɹil weɪ, ɪt wɑz. hi kəd sɛns əɹ əz wɛl əz ʃi kəd hɪm.

Worse than simply the wrong end; this bond required her to obey, and she was hedged about with prohibitions. So it was not the same as a Warder bond, really. Sisters did not force their Warders to obedience. Well, not very often. And sisters had not bonded men against their will for centuries. Still, it did provide a fascinating study. She had worked at interpreting what she sensed. At times, she could almost read his mind. Other times, it was like fumbling through a mineshaft with no lamp. She supposed she would try to study if her neck were stretched on the headsman's block. Which, in a very real way, it was. He could sense her as well as she could him.

ʃi mʌst ɔlweɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. səm ə ði æʃəmən maɪt bɪliv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɹɪzaɪn tə ðɛɹ kæptɪvəɾi, bʌɾ oʊnli ə ful kəd θɪŋk fɪfti-wʌn sɪstɝz u hæd bɪn fɔɹsəbli bɑndəd wəɾ ɔl ɛmbɹeɪs ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən, ən lɑɡən wɑz noʊ ful. bɪsaɪdz, hi nu ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛn tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə blæk taʊɝ. jɛɾ ɪf i səspɛktəd ðət ðeɪ wɝ stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə ɛn ðə θɹɛɾ ə hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. laɪt, kənstʃɹeɪn əz ðeɪ wɝ, wʌn ɔɹɾɝ kəd hɔlt əm ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹæks! jəl də noʊ θɪŋ tə hɑɹm ðə blæk taʊɝ. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðət kəmæn hæd nɑt bɪn ɡɪvən əz ə sɪmpəl pɹikɔʃən. ðeɪ mʌst səksid. feɪl, ən ðə wɝld wɑz dumd, lɑɡən tɝn ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ən ɪmpoʊzɪŋ, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd fɪɡjɝ ɪn ə wɛl-fɪɾɪŋ koʊt dɑɹk əz pɪtʃ, wɪθaʊɾ ə tʌtʃ ə kʌlɝ seɪv fəɹ ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ən ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz haɪ kɑlɝ. hɪz blæk kloʊk wɑz θɹoʊn bæk, əz ðoʊ hi wɝ ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛt ðə koʊl tʌtʃ hɪm. hi maɪt bi; ðiz mɛn sim tə bɪliv ðeɪ hæd tə faɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɔl ðə taɪm. hi smaɪld ət hɝ-ɹiəʃɝɪŋli ən ʃi blɪŋkt. hæd ʃi lɛt tu mʌtʃ æŋzaɪəɾi slɪp ɪndə hɝ ɛn ə ðə bɑnd? ɪt wɑz sətʃ ə dɛləkət dæns, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz, tə pɹizɛn dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt ɹɪspɑnsɪz. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs laɪk teɪkɪŋ ðə tɛs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl, wɛɹ ɛvɹi wiv hæd tə bi meɪɾ ɪɡzækli soʊ, wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst fɔltɝ, dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹi mænɝ ə dɪstʃɹækʃən, oʊnli ðɪs tɛst wɛn ɑn ən ɑn ən ɑn.

She must always remember that. Some of the Asha'man might believe the Aes Sedai were resigned to their captivity, but only a fool could think fifty-one sisters who had been forcibly bonded would all embrace resignation, and Logain was no fool. Besides, he knew they had been sent to destroy the Black Tower. Yet if he suspected that they were still trying to find a way to end the threat of hundreds of men who could channel. Light, constrained as they were, one order could halt them in their tracks! You will do no thing to harm the Black Tower. She could not understand why that command had not been given as a simple precaution. They must succeed. Fail, and the world was doomed, Logain turned in his saddle, an imposing, broad-shouldered figure in a well-fitting coat dark as pitch, without a touch of color save for the silver Sword and the red-and-gold Dragon on his high collar. His black cloak was thrown back, as though he were refusing to let the cold touch him. He might be; these men seemed to believe they had to fight everything, all the time. He smiled at her-reassuringly and she blinked. Had she let too much anxiety slip into her end of the bond? It was such a delicate dance, trying to control her emotions, to present just the right responses. It was almost like taking the test for the shawl, where every weave had to be made exactly so, without the slightest falter, despite every manner of distraction, only this test went on and on and on.

hi tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən ɑn tʌvaɪn, ən ɡɑbɹɛl ɛksheɪl sɔfli. dʒʌst ə smaɪl, ðɛn. ə kəmpænjənəbəl dʒɛstʃɝ. hi wɑz ɔfən kəndʒinjəl. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn laɪkəbəl ɪf i wɝ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt wʌɾ i wɑz.

He turned his attention on Toveine, and Gabrelle exhaled softly. Just a smile, then. A companionable gesture. He was often congenial. He might have been likable if he were anything but what he was.

tʌvaɪn bim bæk ət hɪm, ən ɡɑbɹɛl hæd tə stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝmənt, nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. pʊlɪŋ əɹ hʊɾ ə lɪɾəl fɔɹwɝɾ əz ðoʊ əɡɛns ðə koʊld, soʊ ɪt ʃɛltɝɾ əɹ feɪs waɪl ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ən ɛdʒ tə pik ɝaʊnd, ʃi stʌɾid ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ sɝəptɪʃəsli.
