Toveine beamed back at him, and Gabrelle had to stop herself from shaking her head in wonderment, not for the first time. Pulling her hood a little forward as though against the cold, so it sheltered her face while giving her an edge to peek around, she studied the Red sister surreptitiously.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu ʌv ði ʌðɝ wʊmən sɛd ʃi bɛɹiɾ əɹ heɪts ɪn ʃæloʊ ɡɹeɪvz, ɪf əɾ ɔl, ən tʌvaɪn loʊð mɛn u kəd tʃænəl əz dipli əz ɛni ɹɛd ɡɑbɹɛl hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt. ɛni ɹɛd mʌs dɪspaɪz lɑɡən əblɝ, æftɝ ðə kleɪmz i hæd meɪd, ðət ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɪtsɛlf hæd sɛɾ ɪm ʌp tə bɪkʌm ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. hi maɪɾ i hoʊldɪŋ ɪz saɪləns naʊ, bʌt ðə dæmədʒ wɑz dʌn. ðəɹ wɝ sɪstɝz kæptɪv wɪð əm u lʊkt ət ɹɛdz əz ðoʊ θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ, ət list wɝ kɑɾ ɪn ə tʃɹæp ə ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ.

Everything she knew of the other woman said she buried her hates in shallow graves, if at all, and Toveine loathed men who could channel as deeply as any Red Gabrelle had ever met. Any Red must despise Logain Ablar, after the claims he had made, that the Red Ajah itself had set him up to become a false Dragon. He might he holding his silence now, but the damage was done. There were sisters captive with them who looked at Reds as though thinking they, at least were caught in a trap of their making.

jɛt tʌvaɪn ɔl bʌt sɪmpɝɾ ət hɪm.

Yet Toveine all but simpered at him.

ɡɑbɹɛl bɪɾ əɹ ʌndɝlɪp ɪn pɝplɛks θɔt. tʃɹu, deɪsɑndɝ ən ləməaɪ hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɛvɹiwʌn tə ətʃiv kɔɹdʒəl ɹileɪʃənz wɪð ði æʃəmən u hɛl ðɛɹ bɑnz-ðə mɛn mʌs bi lʌl bɪfɔɹ ðə sɪstɝz kəd də ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl-bʌt tʌvaɪn bɹɪsəld oʊpənli əɾ ɛvɹi kəmæn fɹəm iðɝ sɪstɝ. ʃi hæd dɪtɛstɪd jildɪŋ tə ðɛm, ən maɪɾ əv ɹəfjuzd ɪf ləməaɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɔlsoʊ ɹɛd, noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ʃi hæɾ ədmɪɾəd ɪt mʌs bi soʊ. əɹ ðət noʊ wʌn hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əɹ əθɔɹəɾi wʌns ʃi lɛɾ əm ɪndə kæptɪvəɾi.

Gabrelle bit her underlip in perplexed thought. True, Desandre and Lemai had ordered everyone to achieve cordial relations with the Asha'man who held their bonds-the men must be lulled before the sisters could do anything useful-but Toveine bristled openly at every command from either sister. She had detested yielding to them, and might have refused if Lemai were not also Red, no matter that she had admitted it must be so. Or that no one had recognized her authority once she led them into captivity.

ʃi heɪɾəd ðæt, tu. jɛt ðət wɑz wən ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn smaɪlɪŋ ət lɑɡən.

She hated that, too. Yet that was when she had begun smiling at Logain.

fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, haʊ kəd lɑɡən sɪɾ ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə hɝ bɑn ən teɪk ðət smaɪl əz ɛniθɪŋ bʌt fɹɔd? ɡɑbɹɛl hæd pɪkt ət ðət nɑt bɪfɔɹ, tu, wɪθaʊt kʌmɪŋ kloʊs tə əntiɪŋ ɪt. hi nu tu mʌtʃ əbaʊt tʌvaɪn. noʊɪŋ əɹ ədʒɑ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf. jɛt ɡɑbɹɛl fɛlt əz lɪɾəl səspɪʃən ɪn ɪm wən i lʊkt ət ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ əz wən i lʊkt ət hɝ. hi wɑz hɑɹdli fɹi ʌv səspɪʃən; ðə mæn wɑz dɪstʃɹʌsfəl ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn, ɪt simd. bʌt lɛs ʌv ɛni sɪstɝ ðən ə səm æʃəmən. ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns, iðɝ.

For that matter, how could Logain sit at the other end of her bond and take that smile as anything but fraud? Gabrelle had picked at that knot before, too, without coming close to untying it. He knew too much about Toveine. Knowing her Ajah should have been enough. Yet Gabrelle felt as little suspicion in him when he looked at the Red sister as when he looked at her. He was hardly free of suspicion; the man was distrustful of everyone, it seemed. But less of any sister than of some Asha'man. That made no sense, either.

hiz noʊ ful, ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf. soʊ, waɪ? ən waɪ fəɹ tʌvaɪn, əz wɛl? wʌɾ ɪz ʃi skimɪŋ æt?

He's no fool, she reminded herself. So, why? And why for Toveine, as well? What is she scheming at?

əbɹʌpli, tʌvaɪn flæʃt ðət simɪŋli wɔɹm smaɪl ət hɝ, ən spoʊk əz ɪf ʃi hæd vɔɪst ət list wʌn ə hɝ kwɛstʃənz əlaʊd. "wɪð jə nɪɹ," ʃi mɝmɝɾ ɪn ə mɪst ə bɹɛθ, "hiz bɛɹli əwɛɹ ə mi. juv meɪɾ ɪm jəɹ kæptɪv, sɪstɝ."

Abruptly, Toveine flashed that seemingly warm smile at her, and spoke as if she had voiced at least one of her questions aloud. "With you near," she murmured in a mist of breath, "he's barely aware of me. You've made him your captive, sister."

kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, ɡɑbɹɛl flʌʃt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. tʌvaɪn nɛvɝ meɪd kɑnvɝseɪʃən, ən tə seɪ ʃi dɪsəpɹuvd ʌv ɡɑbɹɛlz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɪð lɑɡən wɑz tə ʌndɝsteɪt dʒɹæstɪkli. sɪdusɪŋ ɪm hæd sim sətʃ ən ɑbviəs weɪ tə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə lɝn ɪz plænz, hɪz wiknəsəz. æftɝ ɔl, ivən ɪf i wɑz ən æʃəmən, ʃi hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i wɑz bɔɹn, ən ʃi wɑz hɑɹdli ə toʊɾəl ɪnəsənt wən ɪt keɪm tə mɛn. hi hæd bɪn soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd wən i ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ðət ʃi ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ ə hɪm əz ði ɪnəsənt. mɔɹ ful ʃi. pleɪɪŋ ðə dəmɑni tɝn aʊt tə haɪd mɛni sɝpɹaɪzəz, ən ə fju pɪtfɔlz. wɝst ʌv ɔl, ə tʃɹæp ʃi kəd nɛvɝ ɹɪvil tə ɛniwʌn. sʌmθɪŋ ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ fɪɹd ðət tʌvaɪn nu, ðoʊ, ət list ɪn pɑɹt. bʌt ðɛn, ɛni sɪstɝ u hæd fɑloʊɾ əɹ lɛd mʌs noʊ, tu, ən ʃi θɔt sɛvɹəl hæd. nʌn hæd spoʊkən ə ðə pɹɑbləm, ən nʌn wɑz laɪkli tə, ʌv kɔɹs.

Caught by surprise, Gabrelle flushed in spite of herself. Toveine never made conversation, and to say she disapproved of Gabrelle's situation with Logain was to understate drastically. Seducing him had seemed such an obvious way to get close enough to learn his plans, his weaknesses. After all, even if he was an Asha'man, she had been Aes Sedai long before he was born, and she was hardly a total innocent when it came to men. He had been so surprised when he realized what she was doing that she almost thought of him as the innocent. More fool she. Playing the Domani turned out to hide many surprises, and a few pitfalls. Worst of all, a trap she could never reveal to anyone. Something she very much feared that Toveine knew, though, at least in part. But then, any sister who had followed her lead must know, too, and she thought several had. None had spoken of the problem, and none was likely to, of course.

lɑɡən kəd mæsk ðə bɑnd, ɪn ə kɹud weɪ ʃi bɪlivd wəd stɪl əlaʊ hɝ tə faɪn ɪm haʊɛvɝ wɛl ɪt hɪɾ ɪz ɪmoʊʃənz, bʌt səmtaɪmz wən ðeɪ ʃɛɹɾ ə pɪloʊ, hi lɛt ðə mæskɪŋ slɪp. tə seɪ ðə list, ðə ɹɪzʌls wɝ ... dɛvəsteɪɾɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɑm ɹɪstʃɹeɪnt, ðɛn, noʊ kul stʌɾi. nɑt mʌtʃ ə ɹizən əɾ ɔl.

Logain could mask the bond, in a crude way she believed would still allow her to find him however well it hid his emotions, but sometimes when they shared a pillow, he let the masking slip. To say the least, the results were ... devastating. There was no calm restraint, then, no cool study. Not much of reason at all.

hɝidli ʃi sʌmən ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə snoʊi lændskeɪp ən fɪkst ɪɾ ɪn əɹ maɪnd. tʃɹiz ən boʊldɝz ən smuð, waɪt snoʊ. smuð, koʊl snoʊ.

Hurriedly she summoned the image of the snowy landscape and fixed it in her mind. Trees and boulders and smooth, white snow. Smooth, cold snow.

lɑɡən dɪd nɔɹ lʊk bæk ət hɝ, əɹ ɡɪv ɛni aʊtwɝd saɪn, bʌt ðə bɑn toʊld əɹ ðəɾ i wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɝ moʊməntɛɹi lɔs ə kəntʃɹoʊl. ðə mæn bɹɪmd wɪð smʌɡnəs! ən sæɾəsfækʃən! ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də nɔɹ tə sið. bʌɾ i wəɾ ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə sið, bɝn hɪm! hi hæd tə noʊ wʌt ʃi fɛl fɹəm hɪm. lɛɾɪŋ əɹ æŋɡɝ ɹaɪz, ðoʊ, oʊnli fɪl ðə fɛloʊ wɪð əmjuzmənt! ən i wɑz nɑɾ ivən ətɛmptɪŋ tə haɪɾ ɪt!

Logain did nor look back at her, or give any outward sign, but the bond told her that he was aware of her momentary loss of control. The man brimmed with smugness! And satisfaction! It was all she could do nor to seethe. But he would expect her to seethe, burn him! He had to know what she felt from him. Letting her anger rise, though, only filled the fellow with amusement! And he was not even attempting to hide it!

tʌvaɪn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə smɔl, sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl, ɡɑbɹɛl noʊɾəst, bʌt ʃi hæɾ oʊnli ə moʊmən tə wʌndɝ waɪ.

Toveine was wearing a small, satisfied smile, Gabrelle noticed, but she had only a moment to wonder why.

ðeɪ hæd ðə mɔɹnɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt naʊ ənʌðɝ ɹaɪɾɝ əpɪɹd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ə kloʊɑkləs mæn ɪn blæk u æŋɡəld ɪz hɔɹs ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən wən i sɔ ðɛm, ən dʌɡ hɪz buθilz ɪndə hɪz ænəməlz flæŋks fəɹ spid dɪspaɪt ðə snoʊ. lɑɡən ɹeɪn ɪn tə weɪt, ði ɪmədʒ ə kɑm, ən ɡɑbɹɛl stɪfən əz ʃi hɔltəɾ əɹ maʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ðə filɪŋz kæɹid baɪ ðə bɑn hæd ʃɪftəd.

They had the morning to themselves, but now another rider appeared through the trees, a cloakless man in black who angled his horse in their direction when he saw them, and dug his bootheels into his animal's flanks for speed despite the snow. Logain reined in to wait, the image of calm, and Gabrelle stiffened as she halted her mount beside him. The feelings carried by the bond had shifted.

naʊ ðeɪ wɝ ðə tɛnʃən ʌv ə wʊlf weɪɾɪŋ tə spɹɪŋ. ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə si hɪz ɡɔntələɾəd hænz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɛstɪŋ əɾ iz ɑn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl.

Now they were the tension of a wolf waiting to spring. She expected to see his gauntleted hands on his sword hilt rather than resting at ease on the tall pommel of his saddle.

ðə nukʌmɝ wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz lɑɡən, wɪð weɪvz ʌv ɡoʊldən hɛɹ tə hɪz waɪd ʃoʊldɝz ən ə wɪnɪŋ smaɪl. ʃi səspɛktəɾ i nu ɪt wɑz ə wɪnɪŋ smaɪl. hi wɑz tu pɹɪɾi nɑt tə noʊ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl ðən lɑɡən. laɪfs fɔɹdʒɪz hæd hɑɹɾənd lɑɡənz feɪs, ən lɛft ɛdʒəz. ðɪs jʌŋ mæn wɑz smuð, jɛt. stɪl, ðə sɔɹɾ ən ðə dʒɹæɡən dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɪz koʊt kɑlɝ. hi stʌɾid ðə tu sɪstɝz wɪð bɹaɪt blu aɪz. "ɑɹ jə bɛɾɪŋ boʊθ ə ðɛm, lɑɡən?" hi sɛɾ ɪn ə dip vɔɪs. "ðə plʌmp wʌn lʊks koʊld-aɪd, tə mi, bʌt ði ʌðɝ əpɪɹz wɔɹm ɪnʌf," tʌvaɪn hɪst æŋɡɹəli ən ɡɑbɹɛlz dʒɔ klɛntʃt. ʃi hæd meɪd noʊ ɹil sikɹəɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi dɪd-ʃi wɑz noʊ kɛɹhinɪn, tə kloʊk ɪn pɹaɪvəsi wʌt ʃi wɑz əʃeɪmd ʌv ɪn pʌblɪk-bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt min ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv ɪt bæntɝɾ əbaʊt-wɝs, ðə mæn spoʊk əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ tævɝn laɪtskɝts!

The newcomer was almost as tall as Logain, with waves of golden hair to his wide shoulders and a winning smile. She suspected he knew it was a winning smile. He was too pretty not to know, much more beautiful than Logain. Life's forges had hardened Logain's face, and left edges. This young man was smooth, yet. Still, the Sword and the Dragon decorated his coat collar. He studied the two sisters with bright blue eyes. "Are you bedding both of them, Logain?" he said in a deep voice. "The plump one looks cold-eyed, to me, but the other appears warm enough," Toveine hissed angrily and Gabrelle's jaw clenched. She had made no real secret of what she did-she was no Cairhienin, to cloak in privacy what she was ashamed of in public-but that did not mean she expected to have it bantered about-Worse, the man spoke as though they were tavern lightskirts!

"doʊn ɛvɝ lemi hɪɹ ðəɾ əɡɛn, mɪʃɹeɪl," lɑɡən sɛd kwaɪətli, ən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðə bɑn hæd tʃeɪnʒd əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz koʊld, naʊ; koʊl tə meɪk ðə snoʊ sim wɔɹm. koʊl tə meɪk ə ɡɹeɪv sim wɔɹm.

"Don't ever let me hear that again, Mishraile," Logain said quietly, and she realized the bond had changed again. It was cold, now; cold to make the snow seem warm. Cold to make a grave seem warm.

ʃi hæd hɝd ðət neɪm bɪfɔɹ, ɑɹəl mɪʃɹeɪl, ən fɛl dɪstʃɹʌst ɪn lɑɡən wən i spoʊk ɪt-sɝɾənli mɔɹ ðən i fɛl fəɹ əɹ əɹ tʌvaɪn-bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə fil ə kɪlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs læfəbəl. ðə mæn hɛld əɹ pɹɪznɝ, jɛɾ i wɑz ɹɛɾi tə də vaɪələns tə dɪfɛn əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən? pɑɹɾ ə hɝ dɪd wɑnə læf, bʌt ʃi tʌk ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əweɪ. ɛni skɹæp maɪt bi jusfəl. ðə jʌŋɡɝ fɛloʊ ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə hɪɹɪŋ ə θɹɛt. hɪz smaɪl nɛvɝ fɔltɝd. "ðə l sɛz jə kən ɡoʊ, ɪf jə wɑnt. kæn si waɪ jud wɑnə teɪk ɑn ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ."

She had heard that name before, Aral Mishraile, and felt distrust in Logain when he spoke it-certainly more than he felt for her or Toveine-but this was the feel of killing. It was almost laughable. The man held her prisoner, yet he was ready to do violence to defend her reputation? Part of her did want to laugh, but she tucked the information away. Any scrap might be useful. The younger fellow gave no sign of hearing a threat. His smile never faltered. "The M'Hael says you can go, if you want. Can't see why you'd want to take on recruiting."

"sʌmwʌn əz tə," lɑɡən ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə lɛvəl toʊn.

"Someone has to," Logain replied in a level tone.

ɡɑbɹɛl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd pʌzəld ɡlænsɪz wɪð tʌvaɪn. waɪ wəd lɑɡən wɑnə ɡoʊ ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ?

Gabrelle exchanged puzzled glances with Toveine. Why would Logain want to go recruiting?

ðeɪ hæd sin pɑɹɾiz ʌv æʃəmən ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðæt, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz taɪɝd fɹəm tʃɹævlɪŋ lɔŋ dɪstənsəz, ən juʒəwəli dɝɾi ən snæpɪʃ bɪsaɪdz. mɛn bɛɹɪŋ ðə dʒɹʌm fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɡɛt ðə wɔɹməst wɛlkəm; ɪt simd ivən bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn lɝnd wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪli æftɝ.

They had seen parties of Asha'man return from that, and they were always tired from Traveling long distances, and usually dirty and snappish besides. Men bearing the drum for the Dragon Reborn did not always get the warmest welcome; it seemed even before anyone learned what they were really after.

ən waɪ wɝ ʃi ən tʌvaɪn dʒʌs hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ɪt. ʃi wʊɾə swɔɹn i toʊld əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wən ðeɪ wɝ laɪɪŋ təɡɛðɝ.

And why were she and Toveine just hearing of it. She would have sworn he told her everything when they were lying together.

mɪʃɹeɪl ʃɹʌɡd. "plɛnti ʌv dɛɾəkeɪtəd ən soʊlʒɝz tə də ðət sɔɹɾ ʌv wɝk. ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ səpoʊz ɪt bɔɹz jə lʊkɪŋ æftɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɔl ðə taɪm. titʃɪŋ fulz tə snik ɝaʊn ɪn ðə wʊdz ən klaɪm klɪfs əz ɪf ðeɪ kʊdn tʃænəl ə wɪskɝ. ivən ə flaɪspɛk vɪlədʒ maɪt lʊk bɛɾɝ." hɪz smaɪl slɪɾ ɪndə ə smɝk, dɪsdeɪnfəl ən nɑɾ əɾ eɪl wɪnɪŋ. "meɪbi ɪf" jə æsk ðə l hɪl lɛt jə dʒɔɪn ɪz klæsəz ət ðə pæləs. jə wʊdn bi bɔɹd ðɛn."

Mishraile shrugged. "Plenty of Dedicated and Soldiers to do that sort of work. Of course, I suppose it bores you looking after training all the time. Teaching fools to sneak around in the woods and climb cliffs as if they couldn't channel a whisker. Even a flyspeck village might look better." His smile slid into a smirk, disdainful and not at ail winning. "Maybe if" you ask the M'Hael he'll let you join his classes at the palace. You wouldn't be bored then."

lɑɡənz feɪs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌt ɡɑbɹɛl fɛlt wʌn ʃɑɹp boʊlt ə fjʊɹi θɹu ðə bɑnd. ʃi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd tɪdbɪts əbaʊt mæzɹim teɪm ən ɪz pɹaɪvət klæsəz, bʌɾ ɔl ɛni ʌv ðə sɪstɝz ɹɪli nu wɑz ðət lɑɡən ən ɪz kɹoʊniz dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs teɪm əɹ ɛni hu ətɛndəɾ ɪz lɛsənz, ən teɪm əpɪɹd nɑt tə tʃɹʌs lɑɡən. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, wʌt ðə sɪstɝz kəd lɝn ə ðə klæsəz wɑz lɪməɾəd; noʊ wʌn wɑz bɑndəd tə ə mæn ə teɪmz fækʃən. səm θɔt ðə mɪstʃɹʌst wɑz kəz boʊθ mɛn hæd kleɪm tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ ivən ə saɪn ə ðə mædnəs ðət tʃænəlɪŋ bɹɔt tə mɛn. ʃi hæd nɑt dɪtɛktəɾ ɛni ɛvəɾəns ʌv ɪnsænəɾi ɪn lɑɡən, ən ʃi wɑtʃt fəɹ ɪɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi wɑtʃt fəɹ saɪnz i wɑz əbaʊt tə tʃænəl. ɪf ʃi wɝ stɪl baʊn tə hɪm wən i wɛn mæd, ɪt maɪt siz əɹ maɪnd, tu. wʌtɛvɝ kɑzd ə kɹæk ɪn ði æʃəmənz ɹæŋks mʌs bi ɛksplɔɪɾəd ðoʊ.

Logain's face never changed, but Gabrelle felt one sharp bolt of fury through the bond. She had overheard tidbits about Mazrim Taim and his private classes, but all any of the sisters really knew was that Logain and his cronies did not trust Taim or any who attended his lessons, and Taim appeared not to trust Logain. Unfortunately, what the sisters could learn of the classes was limited; no one was bonded to a man of Taim's faction. Some thought the mistrust was because both men had claimed to be the Dragon Reborn or even a sign of the madness that channeling brought to men. She had not detected any evidence of insanity in Logain, and she watched for it as hard as she watched for signs he was about to channel. If she were still bound to him when he went mad, it might seize her mind, too. Whatever caused a crack in the Asha'man's ranks must be exploited though.

mɪʃɹeɪlz smaɪl feɪɾəd əz lɑɡən mɪɹli lʊkt ət hɪm.

Mishraile's smile faded as Logain merely looked at him.

"ɛndʒɔɪ jəɹ flaɪspɛks," hi sɛd faɪnəli pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊnd-ə θʌɾ ə hɪz hil meɪd ði ænəməl spɹɪŋ əweɪ əz i kɔld oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "ɡlɔɹi weɪts fəɹ səm ʌv ʌs, lɑɡən."

"Enjoy your flyspecks," he said finally pulling his horse around-A thud of his heel made the animal spring away as he called over his shoulder, "Glory waits for some of us, Logain."

"hi meɪ nɔɹ ɛndʒɔɪ hɪz dʒɹæɡən lɔŋ," lɑɡən mɝmɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝ mæn ɡæləp ɔf- "hiz tu fɹi wɪð ɪz tʌŋ." ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i mɛn ðə kɑmɛn əbaʊɾ əɹ ən tʌvaɪn, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt fæðəm wʌɾ ɛls i kəd min. ən waɪ wɑz i sʌɾənli wɝid? haɪɾɪŋ ɪt vɛɹi wɛl, ɪspɛʃli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə bɑnd, bʌt stɪl, hi wɑz wɝid. laɪt, səmtaɪmz ɪt sim ðət noʊɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɪn ə mænz hɛd meɪd ðə kənfjuʒən wɝs!

"He may nor enjoy his Dragon long," Logain murmured, watching the other man gallop off- "He's too free with his tongue." She did not think he meant the comment about her and Toveine, but she could not fathom what else he could mean. And why was he suddenly worried? Hiding it very well, especially considering the bond, but still, he was worried. Light, sometimes it seemed that knowing what was in a man's head made the confusion worse!

əbɹʌpli hi tɝn ɪz ɡeɪz ɑn əɹ ən tʌvaɪn, stʌɾiɪŋ. ə nu θɹɛɾ ə kənsɝn slɪp θɹu ðə bɑnd. əbaʊt ðɛm? ɔɹ-æn ɑd θɔt- fəɹ ðɛm?

Abruptly he turned his gaze on her and Toveine, studying. A new thread of concern slipped through the bond. About them? Or-an odd thought- for them?

"aɪ fɪɹ wi mʌs kʌt ʃɔɹɾ əɹ ɹaɪd," hi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ hæv pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz tə meɪk." hi dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk ɪndə ə ɡæləp, bʌɾ i stɪl sɛɾ ə kwɪkɝ peɪs bæk təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ ə ðə mɛn ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðən i hæd kʌmɪŋ aʊt. hi wɑz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ, naʊ; θɪŋkɪŋ hɑɹd, ɡɑbɹɛl səspɛktəd. ðə bɑn pɹæktəkli hʌmd wɪð ɪt. hi mʌst əv bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ baɪ ɪnstɪŋkt.

"I fear we must cut short our ride," he said after a moment. "I have preparations to make." He did not break into a gallop, but he still set a quicker pace back toward the village of the men in training than he had coming out. He was concentrating on something, now; thinking hard, Gabrelle suspected. The bond practically hummed with it. He must have been riding by instinct.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn vɛɹi fɑɹ, tʌvaɪn muvd əɹ hɔɹs kloʊs tə ɡɑbɹɛlz. linɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə fɪks ɡɑbɹɛl wɪð ən ɪntɛn stɛɹ waɪl dɑɹɾɪŋ kwɪk ɡlænsɪz ət lɑɡən əz ɪf əfɹeɪɾ i maɪt lʊk bæk ən si ðɛm tɔkɪŋ. ʃi nɛvɝ sim tə peɪ ətɛnʃən tə wʌt ðə bɑn koʊl hɝ. ðə dɪvaɪɾəd ɛfɝt meɪɾ əɹ bɑb əbaʊt laɪk ə pʌpət, ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə fɔlɪŋ.

Before they had gone very far, Toveine moved her horse close to Gabrelle's. Leaning in her saddle, she tried to fix Gabrelle with an intent stare while darting quick glances at Logain as if afraid he might look back and see them talking. She never seemed to pay attention to what the bond cold her. The divided effort made her bob about like a puppet, in danger of falling.

"wi mʌst ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm" ðə ɹɛd wɪspɝd. "wʌtɛvɝ ɪt teɪks, jə mʌst si tə ɪt." ɡɑbɹɛl ɹeɪzd əɹ aɪbɹaʊz, ən tʌvaɪn hæd ðə ɡɹeɪs tə kʌlɝ, bʌt ʃi lɔs nʌθɪŋ ə hɝ ɪnsɪstəns, "wi kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd" ʃi bɹið hɝidli. "ðə mæn dɪdn əbændən ɪz æmbɪʃənz wən i keɪm hɪɹ. wʌtɛvɝ vɪlnəs i plænz, wi kən də nʌθɪŋ ɪf wi ɑɹən ɹaɪt ðəɹ wən i tʃɹaɪz."

"We must go with him" the Red whispered. "Whatever it takes, you must see to it." Gabrelle raised her eyebrows, and Toveine had the grace to color, but she lost nothing of her insistence, "We cannot afford to be left behind" she breathed hurriedly. "The man didn't abandon his ambitions when he came here. Whatever vileness he plans, we can do nothing if we aren't right there when he tries."

"aɪ kən si wʌts ɪn fɹʌn ə maɪ noʊz," ɡɑbɹɛl sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ən fɛlt ɹɪlif wən tʌvaɪn sɪmpli nɑɾəd ən fɛl saɪlənt. ɪt wɑz ɔl ɡɑbɹɛl kəd də tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə fɪɹ ðət wɑz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn hɝ. dɪd tʌvaɪn nɛvɝ θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt ʃi mʌst sɛns θɹu ðə bɑnd? sʌmθɪŋ ðət hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðəɹ ɪn ðə kənɛkʃən wɪð lɑɡən-dɪtɝməneɪʃən-naʊ leɪ hɑɹɾ ən ʃɑɹp əz ə naɪf. ʃi θɔt ʃi nu wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt, ðɪs taɪm, ən noʊɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ maʊθ dʒɹaɪ. əɡɛns hum, ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət lɑɡən əblɝ wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə wɔɹ.

"I can see what's in front of my nose," Gabrelle said sharply, and felt relief when Toveine simply nodded and fell silent. It was all Gabrelle could do to control the fear that was rising in her. Did Toveine never think about what she must sense through the bond? Something that had always been there in the connection with Logain-determination-now lay hard and sharp as a knife. She thought she knew what it meant, this time, and knowing made her mouth dry. Against whom, she could not say but she was sure that Logain Ablar was riding to war.

sloʊli dɪsɛndɪŋ wʌn ə ðə waɪd hɔlweɪz ðət spaɪɹəl dʒɛnli θɹu ðə waɪt taʊɝ, jukɪɝi fɛl pɹɪkli əz ə stɑɹv kæt. ʃi kəd bɛɹli meɪk hɝsɛlf lɪsən tə wʌt ðə sɪstɝ ɡlaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ wɑz seɪɪŋ. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz stɪl dɪm, fɝs laɪt dɑɹkən baɪ ðə snoʊ fɔlɪŋ hɛvəli ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ðə mɪɾəl lɛvəlz ə ðə taʊɝ wɝ əz aɪsi əz ə bɔɹɾɝlənd wɪntɝ. wɛl, pɝhæps nɑt soʊ koʊld əz ðæt, ʃi əlaʊɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ðət fɑɹ nɔɹθ ɪn ə nʌmbɝ ə jɪɹz, ən mɛmɹi ɪkspændəd wʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt ʃɹɪŋk. ðət wɑz ðə ɹizən ɹɪɾən ɹɛkɝdz wɝ soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ɪksɛpt wən jə dɪd nɑt dɛɹ ɹaɪt daʊn ɛniθɪŋ, ət list. stɪl, ɪt wɑz tʃɪl ɪnʌf. fəɹ ɔl ði eɪntʃən bɪldɝz' klɛvɝnəs ən skɪl, hit fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt fɝnəsəz ɪn ðə beɪsmənt nɛvɝ ɹitʃt ðɪs haɪ. dʒɹæfs meɪd ðə fleɪmz dæns ɑn ðə ɡɪldɪd stændlæmps, ən səm wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stɝ ðə hɛvi tæpəstʃɹiz speɪst əlɔŋ ðə waɪt wɔlz, spɹɪŋ flaʊɝz ən wʊdlænz ən ɪɡzɑɾɪk ænəməlz ən bɝdz ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ wɪð sinz ə taʊɝ tʃɹaɪəmfs ðət wəd nɛvɝ bi dɪspleɪɾ ɪn ðə pʌblɪk ɛɹiəz bɪloʊ. hɝ oʊn ɹumz, wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɹm faɪɝpleɪsəz wəd wʌns əv bɪn mʌtʃ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl.

Slowly descending one of the wide hallways that spiraled gently through the White Tower, Yukiri felt prickly as a starved cat. She could barely make herself listen to what the sister gliding beside her was saying. The morning was still dim, first light darkened by the snow falling heavily on Tar Valon and the middle levels of the Tower were as icy as a Borderland winter. Well, perhaps not so cold as that, she allowed after a moment. She had not been that far north in a number of years, and memory expanded what it did not shrink. That was the reason written records were so important. Except when you did not dare write down anything, at least. Still, it was chill enough. For all the ancient builders' cleverness and skill, heat from the great furnaces in the basement never reached this high. Drafts made the flames dance on the gilded standlamps, and some were strong enough to stir the heavy tapestries spaced along the white walls, spring flowers and woodlands and exotic animals and birds alternating with scenes of Tower triumphs that would never be displayed in the public areas below. Her own rooms, with their warm fireplaces would once have been much more comfortable.

nuz fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪd wɝl tʃɝn θɹu hɝ hɛd dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɛfɝts tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt. əɹ ɹæðɝ, mɔɹ ɔfən, ðə læk ə sɑləd nuz. wʌɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɹipɔɹɾəd fɹəm ɔltɑɹə ən ɑɹæd dumən wɑz ɔl kənfjuʒən, ən ðə fju ɹɪpɔɹts bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə sip aʊɾ ə tæɹɑbən əɡɛn wɝ fɹaɪɾənɪŋ. ɹumɝ pʊt ðə bɔɹɾɝlənd ɹulɝz ɛvɹiwɛɹ fɹəm ðə blaɪt tə ændɝ tə ɑmɑdɪʃiə tə ði il weɪst; ði oʊnli kənfɝm fækt wɑz ðət nʌn wɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ. ði il wɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ ən faɪnəli aʊɾ ʌv ælθɹz kəntʃɹoʊl, ɪɾ əpɪɹd, ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ɪn ɪt. ðə leɪɾəst nuz fɹəm mʊɹændi meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ ən wip ət ðə seɪm taɪm, waɪl kɛɹhin...!

News from the outside world churned through her head despite her efforts to avoid it. Or rather, more often, the lack of solid news. What eyes-and-ears reported from Altara and Arad Doman was all confusion, and the few reports beginning to seep out of Tarabon again were frightening. Rumor put the Borderland rulers everywhere from the Blight to Andor to Amadicia to the Aiel Waste; the only confirmed fact was that none were where they were supposed to be, guarding the Blightborder. The Aiel were everywhere and finally out of al'Thor's control, it appeared, if they had ever been in it. The latest news from Murandy made her want to grind her teeth and weep at the same time, while Cairhien...!

sɪstɝz ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sʌn pæləs, səm səspɛktəɾ ə biɪŋ ɹɛbəlz ən nʌn noʊn tə bi lɔɪəl, ən stɪl noʊ wɝɾ ə kɔɪɹən ən əɹ ɛmbəsi sɪns ðeɪ dɪpɑɹɾəd ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn bæk ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn lɔŋ sɪns. ən əz ɪf ðət wɝ nɔɹ ɪnʌf, ælθɹ hɪmsɛlf hæd vænɪʃt laɪk ə soʊp bʌbəl jɛɾ əɡɛn. kəd ðə teɪlz ðəɾ i hæd hæf-dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə sʌn pæləs bi tʃɹu? laɪt, ðə mæn kəd nɑt ɡoʊ mæd jɛt! əɹ hæɾ ɪleɪɾəz wɪtləs ɔfɝ ʌv "pɹətɛkʃən" fɹaɪɾənd ɪm ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ? dɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ fɹaɪɾən hɪm? hi fɹaɪɾənd hɝ. hi fɹaɪɾənd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə hɔl, tu, lɛɾ əm pʊt wʌtɛvɝ feɪs ɑn ɪt ðeɪ wɑntəd.

Sisters all over the Sun Palace, some suspected of being rebels and none known to be loyal, and still no word of Coiren and her embassy since they departed the city, though they should have been back in Tar Valon long since. And as if that were nor enough, al'Thor himself had vanished like a soap bubble yet again. Could the tales that he had half-destroyed the Sun Palace be true? Light, the man could not go mad yet! Or had Elaida's witless offer of "protection" frightened him into hiding? Did anything frighten him? He frightened her. He frightened the rest of the Hall, too, let them put whatever face on it they wanted.

ði oʊnli θɪŋ tʃɹuli sɝɾən wɑz ðət nʌn ə ðət mæɾɝd ə spɪɾ ɪn ə ɹeɪnstɔɹm. noʊɪŋ soʊ dɪd nɑt hɛlp əɹ muɾ ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst. wɝi oʊvɝ biɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ə tæŋɡəl ə ɹoʊzɪz, ivən ɪf ðə θɔɹnz maɪt kɪl jə ɪvɛntʃəwəli, wɑz ə lʌɡʒɝi wən jə hæɾ ə naɪf pɔɪn pɹɛs tə jəɹ ɹɪbz.

The only thing truly certain was that none of that mattered a spit in a rainstorm. Knowing so did not help her mood in the slightest. Worry over being caught in a tangle of roses, even if the thorns might kill you eventually, was a luxury when you had a knife point pressed to your ribs.

"ɛvɹi taɪm ʃiz lɛf ðə taʊɝ ɪn ðə læs tɛn jɪɹz, ɪts bɪn ɑn əɹ oʊn əfɛɹz, soʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ ɹisən ɹɛkɝdz tə tʃɛk," hɝ kəmpænjən mɝmɝd. "ɪts dɪfəkəl tə lɝn ɪɡzækli wən ʃiz bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ən ɹɪmeɪn ... dɪskɹit." hɝ dɑɹk ɡoʊldən hɛɹ hɛl bæk baɪ aɪvɝi koʊmz, maɪdɑni wɑz tɔl, ən slɛndɝ ɪnʌf tə lʊk oʊvɝ-bæləns baɪ hɝ bʊzəm, ən ɪfɛkt ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ boʊθ ðə fɪɾ ə hɝ dɑɹk sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd bɑɾəs ən ðə weɪ ʃi wɔkt ɪn ə stup tə pʊɾ əɹ maʊθ mɔɹ ɑn ðə lɛvəl ə jukɪɝiz ɪɹ. hɝ ʃɔl wɑz kɑɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪsts, ðə lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ fɹɪnʒ dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹtaɪlz.

"Every time she's left the Tower in the last ten years, it has been on her own affairs, so there are no recent records to check," her companion murmured. "It's difficult to learn exactly when she has been out of the Tower and remain ... discreet." Her dark golden hair held back by ivory combs, Meidani was tall, and slender enough to look over-balanced by her bosom, an effect emphasized by both the fit of her dark silver embroidered bodice and the way she walked in a stoop to put her mouth more on the level of Yukiri's ear. Her shawl was caught on her wrists, the long gray fringe dragging on the floortiles.

"stʃɹeɪɾən jəɹ bækboʊn," jukɪɝi ɡɹaʊl kwaɪətli. "maɪ ɪɹz ɑɹən klɔɡd wɪð dɝt." ði ʌðɝ wʊmən dʒɝk hɝsɛlf əpɹaɪt, feɪn splæʃəz ə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks. pʊlɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl haɪɝ ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz. maɪdɑni hæf ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ kaʊɝɾ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ lɛoʊnɪn, hu wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ əɾ ə dɪskɹit dɪstəns. ɪf ðeɪ kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ ðə feɪn tɪŋkəl ə ðə sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn ðə lin mænz blæk bɹeɪdz, ðoʊ, hi kəd hɪɹ nʌθɪŋ sɛɾ ɪn ə mɑɾɝət toʊn. ðə mæn nu noʊ mɔɹ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi-pɹɛʃəs lɪɾəl, ɪn fækt, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd sɝɾən θɪŋz ə hɪm: ðət wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni ɡʊd wɔɹɾɝ-ænd i maɪt kɑz pɹɑbləmz ɪf i lɝn tu mʌtʃ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ wɪspɝɪŋ. pipəl u sɔ wɪspɝɪŋ wɑntəd tə noʊ wʌt ðə sikɹət wɑz.

"Straighten your backbone," Yukiri growled quietly. "My ears aren't clogged with dirt." The other woman jerked herself upright, faint splashes of color in her cheeks. Pulling her shawl higher on her arms. Meidani half glanced over her shoulder coward her Warder Leonin, who was following at a discreet distance. If they could barely hear the faint tinkle of the silver bells in the lean man's black braids, though, he could hear nothing said in a moderate tone. The man knew no more than necessary-precious little, in fact, except that his Aes Sedai wanted certain things of him: that was enough for any good Warder-and he might cause problems if he learned too much, but there was no need for whispering. People who saw whispering wanted to know what the secret was.

ði ʌðɝ ɡɹeɪ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðə sɔɹs ə hɝ ɪɹɪteɪʃən ðən ði aʊtsaɪd wɝld, haʊɛvɝ, ivən ɪf ðə wʊmən wɑz ə dʒækdɔ ɪn swɑnz fɛðɝz. nɑt ðə meɪn sɔɹs, ɛniweɪ. ə dɪsɡʌstɪŋ θɪŋ, ə ɹɛbəl pɹitɛndɪŋ lɔɪəlti, jɛt jukɪɝi wɑz æktʃəli  ɡlæd ðət sɹɪn ən pɛvɑɹə hæd kənvɪnst əɹ ðət ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt jɛt tɝn maɪdɑni ən əɹ sɪstɝ dʒækdɔz oʊvɝ tə taʊɝ lɔ. ðɛɹ wɪŋz wɝ klɪpt, naʊ, ən ðeɪ wɝ jusfəl. ðeɪ maɪɾ ivən ɡeɪn ə mɛʒɝ ə klɛmənsi, fəɹ wən ðeɪ dɪd feɪs dʒʌstəs. ʌv kɔɹs, wən ði oʊθ ðət hæd klɪp maɪdɑniz wɪŋz keɪm aʊt; jukɪɝi maɪɾ izəli ɹaɪn hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ klɛmənsi. ɹɛbəlz əɹ nɑt, wʌt ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz hæd dʌn wɪð maɪdɑni ən əɹ kənfɛɾɝeɪts wɑz əz fɑɹ aʊtsaɪd ðə lɔ əz mɝɾɝ. əɹ tʃɹizən. ən oʊθ ə pɝsənəl oʊbiɾiəns-swɔɹn ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɪtsɛlf; swɔɹn ʌndɝ dʊɹɛs-wɑz ɔl tu kloʊs tə kəmpʌlʃən, wɪtʃ wɑz klɪɹli pɹoʊhɪbəɾəd ɪf nɑt ɹɪli dɪfaɪnd. stɪl, səmtaɪmz jə hæd tə smʌdʒ ðə plæstɝ tə smoʊk aʊt hɔɹnəts, ən ðə blæk ədʒɑ wɝ hɔɹnəts wɪð vɛnəməs stɪŋz. ðə lɔ wəɾ əv ɪts kɔɹs ɪn du taɪm-wɪθaʊt ðə lɔ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ-bʌt ʃi niɾəd tə bi mɔɹ kənsɝnd wɪð wɛðɝ ʃi wəd sɝvaɪv ðə smoʊkɪŋ aʊt ðən wɪð wʌt pɛnəltiz ðə lɔ wəɾ ɪɡzækt. kɔɹpsəz hæd noʊ nid tə wɝi əbaʊt pʌnɪʃmənt.

The other Gray was no more the source of her irritation than the outside world, however, even if the woman was a jackdaw in swan's feathers. Not the main source, anyway. A disgusting thing, a rebel pretending loyalty, yet Yukiri was actually glad that Saerin and Pevara had convinced her that they should not yet turn Meidani and her sister jackdaws over to Tower Law. Their wings were clipped, now, and they were useful. They might even gain a measure of clemency, for when they did face justice. Of course, when the oath that had clipped Meidani's wings came out; Yukiri might easily rind herself wishing for clemency. Rebels or not, what she and the others had done with Meidani and her confederates was as far outside the law as murder. Or treason. An oath of personal obedience-sworn on the Oath Rod itself; sworn under duress-was all too close to Compulsion, which was clearly prohibited if not really defined. Still, sometimes you had to smudge the plaster to smoke out hornets, and the Black Ajah were hornets with venomous stings. The law would have its course in due time-without the law there was nothing-but she needed to be more concerned with whether she would survive the smoking out than with what penalties the law would exact. Corpses had no need to worry about punishment.

ʃi moʊʃən kɝtli fəɹ maɪdɑni tə ɡoʊ ɑn, bʌt noʊ sunɝ hæd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ðən θɹi bɹaʊnz ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ fɹəm ənʌðɝ hɔlweɪ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, flɔntɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz laɪk ɡɹinz. jukɪɝi nu mæɹɪs θɔɹnhɪl ən dɝeɪz mɛsiənz slaɪtli, ɪn ðə mænɝ sɪɾɝz nu sɪstɝz fɹəm ʌðɝ ədʒəz u spɛn lɔŋ pɪɹiədz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, wɪtʃ wɑz tə seɪ ɪnʌf tə ətætʃ neɪmz tə feɪsəz ən nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ. maɪld ən əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðɛɹ stʌɾiz wɑz haʊ ʃi wʊɾə dɪskɹaɪb ðɛm, ɪf pɹɛst. ɛlɪn wɔɹəl wɑz soʊ nuli ɹeɪz tə ðə ʃɔl, ʃi stɪl ʃʊɾə bɪn bɑbɪŋ kɝtsiz ɑn ɪnstɪŋkt. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɔfɝɪŋ kɝɾəsiz tə ə sɪɾɝ, ðoʊ, ɔl θɹi stɛɹɾ ət jukɪɝi ən maɪdɑni ðə weɪ kæts stɛɹɾ ət stʃɹeɪnʒ dɑɡz. əɹ meɪbi dɑɡz ət stʃɹeɪnʒ kæts. noʊ maɪlnəs, ðɛɹ.

She motioned curtly for Meidani to go on, but no sooner had the other woman opened her mouth than three Browns rounded a corner from another hallway right in front of them, flaunting their shawls like Greens. Yukiri knew Marris Thornhill and Doraise Mesianes slightly, in the manner Sitters knew sisters from other Ajahs who spent long periods in the Tower, which was to say enough to attach names to faces and not much more. Mild and absorbed in their studies was how she would have described them, if pressed. Elin Warrel was so newly raised to the shawl, she still should have been bobbing curtsies on instinct. Instead of offering courtesies to a Sitter, though, all three stared at Yukiri and Meidani the way cats stared at strange dogs. Or maybe dogs at strange cats. No mildness, there.

"meɪ aɪ æsk əbaʊɾ ə pɔɪn ə ɝæfɛlən lɔ sɪɾɝ?" maɪdɑni sɛd, əz smuðli əz ɪf ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ɪntɛndɪŋ tə seɪ ɔl əlɔŋ.

"May I ask about a point of Arafellan law Sitter?" Meidani said, as smoothly as if that was what she had been intending to say all along.

jukɪɝi nɑɾəd, ən maɪdɑni bɪɡæn ɹæmblɪŋ əbaʊt fɪʃɪŋ ɹaɪts ɑn ɹɪvɝz vɝsəs leɪks, hɑɹdli ən ɪnspaɪɝd tʃɔɪs. ə mædʒəstʃɹeɪt maɪɾ æsk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə lɪsən tə ə keɪs ə fɪʃɪŋ ɹaɪts, bʌɾ oʊnli tə boʊlstɝ əɹ oʊn əpɪnjən ɪf paʊɝfəl pipəl wɝ ɪnvɑlvd ən ʃi wɑz wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ ən əpil tə ðə θɹoʊn.

Yukiri nodded, and Meidani began rambling about fishing rights on rivers versus lakes, hardly an inspired choice. A magistrate might ask an Aes Sedai to listen to a case of fishing rights, but only to bolster her own opinion if powerful people were involved and she was worried about an appeal to the throne.

ə sɪŋɡəl wɔɹɾɝ tʃɹeɪl ðə bɹaʊnz-jukɪɝi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl wɛðɝ i bɪlɔŋ tə mæɹɪs əɹ dɝeɪz-ə hɛvi-sɛt fɛloʊ wɪð ə hɑɹd ɹaʊn feɪs ən ə dɑɹk tɑp-nɑɾ u aɪd lɛoʊnɪn ən ðə sɔɹdz ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð ə dɪstʃɹʌst ʃʊɹli pɪkt ʌp fɹəm ɪz sɪstɝ. ðət pɛɹ stɔk baɪ ʌp ðə sloʊli spaɪɹəlɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ wɪð plʌmp tʃɪnz haɪ, ðə skɪni nulɪŋ lipɪŋ æŋkʃəsli tə kip ʌp. ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʃɹoʊɾ æftɝ əm ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ ði ɛɹ ʌv ə mæn ɪn hɑstəl kʌntʃɹi.

A single Warder trailed the Browns-Yukiri could not recall whether he belonged to Marris or Doraise-a heavy-set fellow with a hard round face and a dark top-knot who eyed Leonin and the swords on his back with a distrust surely picked up from his sister. That pair stalked by up the slowly spiraling corridor with plump chins high, the skinny newling leaping anxiously to keep up. The Warder strode after them radiating the air of a man in hostile country.

hɑstɪləɾi wɑz ɔl tu juʒəwəl, naʊədeɪz. ði ɪnvɪzəbəl wɔlz bɪtwin ði ədʒəz, wʌns bɛɹli θɪk ɪnʌf tə haɪɾ itʃ ədʒɑz oʊn mɪstɝiz, hæd bɪkʌm hɑɹd stoʊn ɹæmpɑɹts wɪð moʊts. noʊ, nɑt moʊts; tʃæzəmz, dip ən waɪd. sɪstɝz nɛvɝ lɛf ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒɑz kɔɹɾɝz əloʊn, ɔfən tʊk ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz ivən tə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi ən ðə daɪnɪŋ ɹumz, ən ɔlweɪz wɔɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔlz, əz ðoʊ sʌmwʌn maɪt mɪsteɪk ðɛɹ ədʒɑ, ʌðɝwaɪz. jukɪɝi hɝsɛlf wɑz wɛɹɪŋ əɹ bɛst, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn sɪlvɝ ən θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld, wɪð ðə lɔŋ sɪlk fɹɪnʒ ðət hʌŋ tə hɝ æŋkəlz. soʊ ʃi səpoʊzd ʃi wɑz flɔntɪŋ əɹ ədʒɑ ə bɪt, tu.

Hostility was all too usual, nowadays. The invisible walls between the Ajahs, once barely thick enough to hide each Ajah's own mysteries, had become hard stone ramparts with moats. No, not moats; chasms, deep and wide. Sisters never left their own Ajah's quarters alone, often took their Warders even to the library and the dining rooms, and always wore their shawls, as though someone might mistake their Ajah, otherwise. Yukiri herself was wearing her best, embroidered in silver and thread-of-gold, with the long silk fringe that hung to her ankles. So she supposed she was flaunting her Ajah a bit, too.

ən leɪtli, ʃi hæd bɪn kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ ə dʌzən jɪɹz wɑz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ. ə hɔɹəbəl θɔt, wʌns ʃi sɪftɪɾ aʊt ðə sɔɹs. noʊ sɪstɝ ʃəɾ əv niɾ ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ ɪnsaɪd ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

And lately, she had been considering that a dozen years was long enough to go without a Warder. A horrible thought, once she sifted out the source. No sister should have need of a Warder inside the White Tower.

nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ðə θɔt hɪɾ əɹ hɑɹd ðət sʌmwʌn hæd tə miɾieɪt əmʌŋ ði ədʒəz, ən sun, əɹ ðə ɹɛbəlz wəd dæns ɪn θɹu ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ, boʊld əz θivz, ən ɛmpti ðə haʊs waɪl ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm skwɑbəld oʊvɝ u ɡɑt ɡɹeɪt-æn sumiz pjuɾɝ. bʌt ði oʊnli ɛn ə ðə θɹɛd ʃi kəd si tə bɪɡɪn wɝkɪŋ aʊt ðə snɑɹl wɑz tə hæv maɪdɑni ən tiɹ fɹɛnz pʌblɪkli ədmɪt ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛn tə ðə taʊɝ baɪ ðə ɹɛbəlz tə spɹɛd ɹumɝz-teɪlz ðeɪ stɪl ɪnsɪstəd wɝ tʃɹu! -ðæt ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hæd kɹieɪɾəd lɑɡən əz ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. kəɾ ɪt bi tʃɹu. wɪθaʊt pɛvɑɹə noʊɪŋ? ɪmpɑsəbəl tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ə sɪɾɝ, ɪspɛʃli pɛvɑɹə, cʊɾə bɪn fuld. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðət bɪɾ ə ðə tæŋɡəl hæd bɪn oʊvɝleɪd wɪð soʊ mɛni ʌðɝz baɪ naʊ ðəɾ ɪt skɛɹsli kəd meɪk ɛni dɪfɝəns baɪ ɪtsɛlf. bɪsaɪdz, ɪt wəd θɹoʊ əweɪ ði eɪɾ ə tɛn aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹtin wɪmən ʃi kəd bi ʃʊɹ wɝ nɑt blæk ədʒɑ, nɑt tə mɛnʃən laɪkli ɪkspoʊzɪŋ wʌt ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm wɝ duɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ ðə stɔɹm oʊvɝ ɪt blu aʊt.

Not for the first time, the thought hit her hard that someone had to mediate among the Ajahs, and soon, or the rebels would dance in through the front door, bold as thieves, and empty the house while the rest of them squabbled over who got great-aunt Sumi's pewter. But the only end of the thread she could see to begin working out the snarl was to have Meidani and tier friends publicly admit that they had been sent to the Tower by the rebels to spread rumors-tales they still insisted were true! -That the Red Ajah had created Logain as a false Dragon. Could it be true. Without Pevara knowing? Impossible to think that a Sitter, especially Pevara, could have been fooled. In any case, that bit of the tangle had been overlaid with so many others by now that it scarcely could make any difference by itself. Besides, it would throw away the aid of ten out of the fourteen women she could be sure were not Black Ajah, not to mention likely exposing what the rest of them were doing, before the storm over it blew out.

ʃi ʃɪvɝd, ən ɪt hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð dʒɹæfs ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ʃi ən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən u maɪt ɹɪvil ðə tʃɹuθ wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ ðət stɔɹm ɛndəd, baɪ soʊ-kɔld æksəɾənt əɹ ɪn bɛd. əɹ ʃi maɪt dʒʌs vænɪʃ, əpɛɹənli ɡɔn aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ nɛvɝ tə bi sin əɡɛn. ʃi hæd noʊ daʊɾ ə ðæt.

She shivered, and it had nothing to do with drafts in the corridor. She and every other woman who might reveal the truth would die before that storm ended, by so-called accident or in bed. Or she might just vanish, apparently gone out of the Tower never to be seen again. She had no doubt of that.

ɛni ɛvəɾəns wəd bi bɛɹid, soʊ dip; ən ɑɹmi wɪð ʃʌvəlz kəd nɛvɝ dɪɡ ɪɾ ʌp. ivən ɹumɝz wəd bi plæstɝɾ oʊvɝ. ɪt hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ. ðə wɝld ən moʊst sɪstɝz stɪl bɪliv tæmɹə ɑspɪnjə hæd daɪɾ ɪn əɹ bɛd. ʃi hæd bɪlivd ɪt. ðeɪ hæd tə hæv ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɹæpt ʌp ən taɪɾ əz nɪɹ əz pɑsəbəl, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɛɹd ɹɪsk ɡoʊɪŋ pʌblɪk.

Any evidence would be buried, so deep; an army with shovels could never dig it up. Even rumors would be plastered over. It had happened before. The world and most sisters still believed Tamra Ospenya had died in her bed. She had believed it. They had to have the Black Ajah wrapped up and tied as near as possible, before they dared risk going public.

maɪdɑni tʊk ʌp əɹ ɹipɔɹɾ əɡɛn wʌns ðə bɹaʊnz wɝ seɪfli pæst, bʌt fɛl saɪlən oʊnli moʊməns leɪɾɝ wɛn, dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, ə bɪɡ hɛɹi hæn sʌɾənli θɹʌst əsaɪɾ ə tæpəstʃɹi fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. ən aɪsi dʒɹæf swɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə dɔɹweɪ ðət hæd bɪn hɪɾən baɪ ðə tæpəstʃɹiz bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd bɝdz fɹəm ðə dʒɹaʊn lænz, ən ə hɛvi fɛloʊ ɪn ə θɪk bɹaʊn wɝk koʊt bækt ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, pʊlɪŋ ə hændkɑɹt stæk haɪ wɪð splɪt hɪkɝi ðəɾ ənʌðɝ sɝvɪŋ mæn ɪn ə ɹʌf koʊt wɑz pʊʃɪŋ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd.

Meidani took up her report again once the Browns were safely past, but fell silent only moments later when, just ahead of them, a big hairy hand suddenly thrust aside a tapestry from behind. An icy draft swept out of the doorway that had been hidden by the tapestry's brightly colored birds from the Drowned Lands, and a heavy fellow in a thick brown work coat backed into the corridor, pulling a handcart stacked high with split hickory that another serving man in a rough coat was pushing from behind.

kɑmən leɪbɝɝz; niðɝ hæd ðə waɪt fleɪm ɑn ɪz tʃɛst.

Common laborers; neither had the white Flame on his chest.

ət saɪɾ ə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ðə mɛn heɪstəli lɛt ðə tæpəstʃɹi fɔl bæk ɪndə pleɪs ən ɹɛsəl ðɛɹ kɑɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ əɡɛns ðə wɔl waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ðɛɹ baʊz, ɔlmoʊs tɑpəlɪŋ ðə loʊd, wɪtʃ sɛɾ əm ɡɹæbɪŋ ət ðə slaɪɾɪŋ faɪɝ-wʊd fɹæntəkəli. noʊ daʊt ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə fɪnɪʃ ðɛɹ wɝk wɪθaʊɾ ɛnkaʊntɝɪŋ ɛni sɪstɝz. jukɪɝi ɔlweɪz fɛl sɪmpəθi fəɹ ðə pipəl u hæd tə hɔl wʊɾ ən wɔɾɝ ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ʌp ðə sɝvəns' ɹæmps ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ʃi stʃɹoʊd pæst əm wɪð ə skaʊl. tɔk waɪl wɔkɪŋ wɑz nɛvɝ oʊvɝhɝd, ən ðə hɔlweɪz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɛɹiəz hæd simd ə ɡʊd pleɪs tə bi pɹaɪvət wɪð maɪdɑni. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən əɹ oʊn əpɑɹtməns, wɛɹ ɛni wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ wəɾ oʊnli ənaʊns tə ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ kɔɹɾɝ ðət ʃi wɑz dɪskʌsɪŋ sikɹəts, ən fɑɹ wɝs, wɪð hum. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli tu hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ ət ðə moʊmənt, ə nʌmbɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəd swɑloʊ ən sim veɪkənt, ən wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn kipɪŋ tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə kɑmən ɛɹiəz ʃʊɾə bɪn ɛmpti. soʊ ʃi hæd θɔt.

At sight of two Aes Sedai the men hastily let the tapestry fall back into place and wrestled their cart out of the way against the wall while trying to make their bows, almost toppling the load, which set them grabbing at the sliding fire-wood frantically. No doubt they had expected to finish their work without encountering any sisters. Yukiri always felt sympathy for the people who had to haul wood and water and everything else up the servants' ramps all the way from the ground, but she strode past them with a scowl. Talk while walking was never overheard, and the hallways in the common areas had seemed a good place to be private with Meidani. Much better than her own apartments, where any ward against eavesdropping would only announce to everyone in the Gray quarter that she was discussing secrets, and far worse, with whom. There were only two hundred or so sisters in the Tower at the moment, a number the White Tower could swallow and seem vacant, and with everyone keeping to themselves, the common areas should have been empty. So she had thought.

ʃi hæd teɪkən ɪndə əkaʊn ðə laɪvən sɝvəns ɹʌʃɪŋ əbaʊt tə tʃɛk læmpwɪks ən ɔɪl lɛvəlz ən ə dʌzən ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ən ðə pleɪn-klæd wɝkɝz kæɹiɪŋ wɪkɝ bæskəts ə ðə laɪt nu wʌɾ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz əbaʊɾ ɪn ði ɝli aʊɝz, ɹɛɾiɪŋ ðə taʊɝ fəɹ ðə deɪ, bʌt ðeɪ meɪd heɪsti baʊz ən kɝtsiz ən skɝid tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə sɪstɝz weɪ. aʊɾ ə hɪɹɪŋ. taʊɝ sɝvəns nu haʊ tə bi tækfəl, ɪspɛʃli sɪns ɛniwʌn ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn ə sɪstɝ wəd bi ʃoʊn ðə dɔɹ. ɡɪvən ðə pɹɛzən muɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ðə sɝvəns wɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli kwɪk tə əvɔɪd soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə tʃæns ʌv oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ θɪŋz ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt.

She had taken into account the livened servants rushing about to check lampwicks and oil levels and a dozen other things, and the plain-clad workers carrying wicker baskets of the Light knew what on their backs. They were always about in the early hours, readying the Tower for the day, but they made hasty bows and curtsies and scurried to get out of a sister's way. Out of hearing. Tower servants knew how to be tactful, especially since anyone eavesdropping on a sister would be shown the door. Given the present mood in the Tower, the servants were particularly quick to avoid so much as a chance of overhearing things they should not.

wʌt ʃi hæd feɪl tə ɹɛkən ɑn wɑz haʊ mɛni sɪstɝz wəd tʃuz tə wɔk aʊtsaɪd ðə kɔɹɾɝz, baɪ tuz ən θɹiz, dɪspaɪt ði aʊɝ ən ðə koʊld, ɹɛdz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛɹ daʊn ɛniwʌn ðeɪ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ɪksɛpt ʌðɝ ɹɛdz. ɡɹinz ən jɛloʊz kəmpiɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɹaʊn ə hɔɾi ən bɹaʊnz duɪŋ ðɛɹ bɛs tə aʊtdu boʊθ. ə fju waɪts, ɔl bʌt wʌn wɔɹɾɝləs, ətɛmptəd tə meɪnteɪn ə fəsɑɾ ə kul ɹizən waɪl dʒʌmpɪŋ ət ðɛɹ oʊn fʊtfɔlz. wʌn lɪɾəl ɡɹup wɑz nɑɾ aʊɾ ə saɪt fəɹ mɔɹ ðən mɪnəts; ɪt simd, bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ əpɪɹd, soʊ maɪdɑni spɛnt nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ taɪm tʃæɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt pɔɪns ə lɔ əz ʃi dɪd ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ɹipɔɹt.

What she had failed to reckon on was how many sisters would choose to walk outside the quarters, by twos and threes, despite the hour and the cold, Reds trying to stare down anyone they encountered except other Reds. Greens and Yellows competing for the crown of haughty and Browns doing their best to outdo both. A few Whites, all but one Warderless, attempted to maintain a facade of cool reason while jumping at their own footfalls. One little group was not out of sight for more than minutes; it seemed, before another appeared, so Meidani spent nearly as much time chattering about points of law as she did giving her report.

wɝst ʌv ɔl, twaɪs ɡɹeɪz smaɪld ɪn wʌt lʊk laɪk ɹɪlif ɑn siɪŋ ʌðɝz ə ðɛɹ ədʒɑ, ən wʊɾə dʒɔɪn əm hæd jukɪɝi nɔɹ ʃeɪkən əɹ hɛd. wɪtʃ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd əɹ noʊ ɛn kəz ɪt lɛɾ ɔl u sɔ noʊ ʃi hæd spɛʃəl ɹizən tə bi əloʊn wɪð maɪdɑni. ivən ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs, ən ðə laɪt sɛn ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən ðeɪ ʃʊd, tu mɛni sɪstɝz spaɪɾ ɑn ʌðɝ ədʒəz ðiz deɪz, ən ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə θɹi oʊðz, ðə teɪlz ðeɪ kæɹid sʌmhaʊ ɡɹu ɪn ðə kæɹiɪŋ. wɪð ɪleɪɾə əpɛɹənli daɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs ði ədʒəz ɪndə laɪn baɪ bɹut fɔɹs, ðoʊz teɪlz tu ɔfən ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn pɛnənsɪz, ən ðə bɛs tə bi hoʊp fəɹ wɑz ðət jə kəd pɹitɛn tə hæv tʃoʊzən tə ɹeɪk ɪɾ ɑn fəɹ ɹizənz ə jəɹ oʊn. jukɪɝi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sʌfɝd θɹu wʌn sʌtʃ, ən ʃi hæd noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə weɪs deɪz skɹʌbɪŋ flɔɹz əɡɛn, ɪspɛʃli naʊ ðət ʃi hæd mɔɹ ɑn əɹ pleɪt ðən ʃi nu wʌt tə də wɪð. ən teɪkɪŋ ði ɔltɝnəɾɪv, ə pɹaɪvət vɪzət tə sɪlviænə, wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ, ivən ɪf ɪt dɪd seɪv taɪm! ɪleɪɾə sim fɪɹsɝ ðən ɛvɝ sɪns ʃi sʌmən sɪlviænə fəɹ əɹ oʊn səpoʊzədli pɹaɪvət pɛnəns. ðə hoʊl taʊɝ wɑz stɪl bʌzɪŋ wɪð ðæt.

Worst of all, twice Grays smiled in what looked like relief on seeing others of their Ajah, and would have joined them had Yukiri nor shaken her head. Which infuriated her no end because it let all who saw know she had special reason to be alone with Meidani. Even if the Black Ajah took no notice, and the Light send there was no reason they should, too many sisters spied on other Ajahs these days, and in spite of the Three Oaths, the tales they carried somehow grew in the carrying. With Elaida apparently dying to force the Ajahs into line by brute force, those tales too often resulted in penances, and the best to be hoped for was that you could pretend to have chosen to rake it on for reasons of your own. Yukiri had already suffered through one such, and she had no desire to waste days scrubbing floors again, especially now that she had more on her plate than she knew what to do with. And taking the alternative, a private visit to Silviana, was no better, even if it did save time! Elaida seemed fiercer than ever since she summoned Silviana for her own supposedly private penance. The whole Tower was still buzzing with that.

əz mʌtʃ əz jukɪɝi heɪɾəd ædmɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl ðət meɪɾ əɹ kɛɹfəl haʊ ʃi lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ʃi sɔ. lʊk tu lɔŋ, ən jə maɪt sim tə bi spaɪɪŋ jɝsɛlf. ʃɪf jəɹ ɡeɪz əweɪ tu fæst, ən jə lʊk fɝɾɪv, wɪð ðə seɪm ɹɪzʌlt. ivən soʊ, ʃi kəd bɛɹli kip əɹ aɪz fɹəm lɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɑn wʌn pɛɹ ə jɛloʊz u ɡlaɪɾɪd əlɔŋ ə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ laɪk kwinz ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn pæləs.

As much as Yukiri hated admitting it all that made her careful how she looked at the other sisters she saw. Look too long, and you might seem to be spying yourself. Shift your gaze away too fast, and you looked furtive, with the same result. Even so, she could barely keep her eyes from lingering on one pair of Yellows who glided along a crossing corridor like queens in their own palace.

ðə dɑɹk stɑki wɔɹɾɝ fɑloʊɪŋ dʒʌs fɑɹ ɪnʌf bɪhaɪn tə ɡɪv əm pɹaɪvəsi mʌst əv bɪlɔŋ tə pɹaɪɾəl nɝbaɪdʒɑn, ə ɡɹin-aɪd wʊmən u hæd lɑɹdʒli ɪskeɪp ðə sɑldəiən noʊz, kəz əɾəən lɹɪsɪt hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝ. jukɪɝi nu lɪɾəl əbaʊt pɹaɪɾəl, bʌt ʃi wəd lɝn mɔɹ æftɝ siɪŋ əɹ ɪn kloʊs kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð əɾəən. ɪn haɪ-nɛkt ɡɹeɪ slæʃt wɪð jɛloʊ ən ə sɪlk-fɹɪnd ʃɔl, ðə tæɹɑbənɝ wɑz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ. hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ, ɪn θɪn, bɹaɪtli biɾɪd bɹeɪdz ðət hʌŋ tə hɝ weɪst, fɹeɪmd ə feɪs ðət sʌmhaʊ sim pɝfəkt əz ɪt wɑz wɪθaʊt biɪŋ bjuɾəfəl. ʃi wɑz ivən fɛɹli mɑɾəst, ət list əz jɛloʊz wɛnt. bʌt ʃi wɑz ðə wʊmən maɪdɑni ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʌɾi wɪθaʊt biɪŋ kɑɾ aʊt. ðə wʊmən huz neɪm ðeɪ wɝ əfɹeɪd tə spik əlaʊɾ ɪksɛp bɪhaɪn stʃɹɔŋ wɔɹdz, əɾəən lɹɪsɪt wɑz wʌn ʌv oʊnli θɹi blæk sɪstɝz tælin nu. ðət wɑz haʊ ðeɪ ɔɹɡənaɪz ðɛmsɛlvz; θɹi wɪmən u nu itʃ ʌðɝ, wɪð itʃ noʊɪŋ wʌn mɔɹ ði ʌðɝ tu dɪd nɑt.

The dark stocky Warder following just far enough behind to give them privacy must have belonged to Pritalle Nerbaijan, a green-eyed woman who had largely escaped the Saldaean nose, because Atuan Larisett had no Warder. Yukiri knew little about Pritalle, but she would learn more after seeing her in close conversation with Atuan. In high-necked gray slashed with yellow and a silk-fringed shawl, the Taraboner was striking. Her dark hair, in thin, brightly beaded braids that hung to her waist, framed a face that somehow seemed perfect as it was without being beautiful. She was even fairly modest, at least as Yellows went. But she was the woman Meidani and the others were trying to study without being caught out. The woman whose name they were afraid to speak aloud except behind strong wards, Atuan Larisett was one of only three Black sisters Talene knew. That was how they organized themselves; three women who knew each other, with each knowing one more the other two did not.

əɾəən hæd bɪn tælinz "wʌn mɔɹ," soʊ ðəɹ wɑz səm hoʊp ʃi kəd bi fɑloʊd tə tu ʌðɝz.

Atuan had been Talene's "one more," so there was some hope she could be followed to two others.

dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə pɛɹ pæst aʊɾ ə vju bɪɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ, əɾəən ɡlænst ʌp ðə spaɪɹəl hɔlweɪ.

Just before the pair passed out of view beyond the corner, Atuan glanced up the spiral hallway.

hɝ ɡeɪz oʊnli bɹʌʃt baɪ jukɪɝi, jɛt ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk jukɪɝiz hɑɹt lip ɪndə hɝ θɹoʊt. ʃi kɛpt wɔkɪŋ, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ feɪs kɑm wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ən ɹɪskt ə kwɪk ɡlæns ə hɝ oʊn wən ʃi ɹitʃt ðə kɔɹnɝ. əɾəən ən pɹaɪɾəl wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi wɛl əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ði aʊɾɝ ɹɪŋ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɪn ðə weɪ, bʌt niðɝ wɑz lʊkɪŋ bæk. pɹaɪɾəl wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd-tə sʌmθɪŋ əɾəən wɑz seɪɪŋ? ðeɪ wɝ tu fɑɹ fəɹ jukɪɝi tə hɪɹ ɛni saʊn ʌðɝ ðən ðə feɪn klɪk ə ðə dɑɹk wɔɹɾɝz buθilz ɑn ðə flɔɹ-taɪlz. ɪt hæd dʒʌs bɪn ə ɡlæns. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt hæd. ʃi kwɪkən əɹ stɛp tə teɪk əɹ bɪɑn saɪɾ ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm dɪd lʊk oʊvɝ ə ʃoʊldɝ, ən lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ ʃi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz hoʊldɪŋ. maɪdɑni ɛkoʊɾ əɹ feɪnli hɝ ʃoʊldɝz sæɡɪŋ.

Her gaze only brushed by Yukiri, yet that was enough to make Yukiri's heart leap into her throat. She kept walking, holding her face calm with an effort, and risked a quick glance of her own when she reached the corner. Atuan and Pritalle were already well along the corridor, heading toward the outer ring. The Warder was in the way, but neither was looking back. Pritalle was shaking her head-To something Atuan was saying? They were too far for Yukiri to hear any sound other than the faint click of the dark Warder's bootheels on the floor-tiles. It had just been a glance. Of course, it had. She quickened her step to take her beyond sight if one of them did look over a shoulder, and let out a long breath she had not realized she was holding. Meidani echoed her faintly her shoulders sagging.

stʃɹeɪnʒ, haʊ ɪt teɪks ʌs, jukɪɝi θɔt, skwɛɹɪŋ əɹ oʊn ʃoʊldɝz. wən ðeɪ fɝs lɝn tælin wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd; tælin hæd bɪn ə ʃildɪd pɹɪznɝ. ən ʃi stɪl skɛɹd spɪtləs, ʃi ədmɪɾəd tə hɝsɛlf. wɛl, wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə meɪk əɹ kənfɛs hæd skɛɹɾ əm spɪtləs fɝst, bʌt lɝnɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ tɝn ðɛɹ tʌŋz tə dʌst. naʊ tælin wɑz tɛðɝd taɪɾɝ ðən maɪdɑni, kloʊsli ɡɑɹɾəd ivən ɪf ʃi dɪɾ əpɪɹ tə wɔk fɹi-haʊ tə kip ə sɪɾɝ pɹɪznɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛniwʌn noʊɾɪsɪŋ hæd bɪn bɪɑn ivən sɹɪn-ænd ʃi wɑz pəθɛɾɪkəli iɡɝ tə ɔfɝ ʌp ɛvɹi skɹæp ʃi nu əɹ ivən səspɛktəɾ ɪn hoʊp ɪt maɪt seɪv əɹ laɪf nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni tʃɔɪs. hɑɹdli ən əbdʒɛkt ə fɪɹ. əz fəɹ ðə ɹɛst...

Strange, how it takes us, Yukiri thought, squaring her own shoulders. When they first learned Talene was a Darkfriend; Talene had been a shielded prisoner. And she still scared spitless, she admitted to herself. Well, what they did to make her confess had scared them spitless first, but learning the truth turned their tongues to dust. Now Talene was tethered tighter than Meidani, closely guarded even if she did appear to walk free-how to keep a Sitter prisoner without anyone noticing had been beyond even Saerin-and she was pathetically eager to offer up every scrap she knew or even suspected in hope it might save her life not that she had any choice. Hardly an object of fear. As for the rest...

pɛvɑɹə hæd tʃɹaɪd tə meɪnteɪn ðət tælin mʌs bi ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ɡəlinə kæsbən, ən wɛn ɪndə ə ɹeɪdʒ ðət læstəɾ ə fʊl deɪ wən ʃi faɪnəli wɑz kənvɪns ðəɾ əɹ ɹɛd sɪstɝ wɑz ɹɪli blæk. ʃi stɪl spoʊk ə stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ ɡəlinə wɪð əɹ oʊn hænz. jukɪɝi hɝsɛlf hæd fɛlt ə koʊl dɪtætʃmənt wən təmeɪl kɪndɝəd wɑz neɪmd. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ɪt stʊd tə ɹizən səm hæd tə bi ɡɹeɪz, ðoʊ pɝhæps dɪsləkɪŋ təmeɪl hɛlpt. ʃi ɹɪmeɪn kul ivən æftɝ ʃi dɪd daɪ sʌmz ən ɹilaɪz ðət təmeɪl hæd lɛf ðə taʊɝ ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət θɹi sɪstɝz wɝ mɝɾɝd. ðət pɹəvaɪɾəd mɔɹ neɪmz fəɹ səspɪʃən, ʌðɝ sɪstɝz u hæd ɡɔn ðɛn, tu, bʌt ɡəlinə ən təmeɪl ən ðə ɹɛst wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, bɪɑn ɹitʃ fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ən oʊnli ðə tu kəd bi pɹuvən dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

Pevara had tried to maintain that Talene must be wrong about Galina Casban, and went into a rage that lasted a full day when she finally was convinced that her Red sister was really Black. She still spoke of strangling Galina with her own hands. Yukiri herself had felt a cold detachment when Temaile Kinderode was named. If there were Darkfriends in the Tower, it stood to reason some had to be Grays, though perhaps disliking Temaile helped. She remained cool even after she did die sums and realized that Temaile had left the Tower at the same time that three sisters were murdered. That provided more names for suspicion, other sisters who had gone then, too, but Galina and Temaile and the rest were out of the Tower, beyond reach for the moment, and only the two could be proven Darkfriends.

əɾəən wɑz ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, blæk ədʒɑ wɪθaʊt daʊt, wɔkɪŋ ðə taʊɝ əz ʃi wɪʃt, ʌnɹistʃɹeɪn ən ənbaʊn ə ðə θɹi oʊðz. ən əntɪl dʌsin kəɾ ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ əɹ tə bi kwɛstʃən ɪn sikɹət-ə dɪfəkəl mæɾɝ, ivən fəɹ ə sɪɾɝ ʌv əɾəənz ədʒɑ, sɪns ɪt hæd tə bi sikɹət fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn-əntɪl ðɛn, ɔl ðeɪ kəd də wɑz wɑtʃ. ə dɪstənt, kɛɹfəli sɝkəmspɛkt wɑtʃɪŋ. ɪt wɑz laɪk lɪvɪŋ wɪð ə ɹɛɾ æɾɝ, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ wən jə wəd faɪn jɝsɛlf aɪ-tə-aɪ wɪð ɪt, nɛvɝ noʊɪŋ wən ɪt maɪt baɪt. laɪk lɪvɪŋ ɪn ə dɛn ə ɹɛɾ æɝz, ən oʊnli biɪŋ eɪbəl tə si wʌn.

Atuan was right there, Black Ajah without doubt, walking the Tower as she wished, unrestrained and unbound of the Three Oaths. And until Doesine could arrange for her to be questioned in secret-a difficult matter, even for a Sitter of Atuan's Ajah, since it had to be secret from everyone-until then, all they could do was watch. A distant, carefully circumspect watching. It was like living with a red adder, never knowing when you would find yourself eye-to-eye with it, never knowing when it might bite. Like living in a den of red adders, and only being able to see one.

sʌɾənli, jukɪɝi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə waɪd, kɝvɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz ɛmpti əhɛɾ əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd si, ən ə ɡlæns bæk ʃoʊɾ oʊnli lɛoʊnɪn bɪhaɪnd. ðə taʊɝ maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛmpti seɪv ə ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. nʌθɪŋ ɪn saɪt muvd ɪksɛp ðə flɪkɝɪŋ fleɪmz ɑn ðə stæn læmps. saɪləns. maɪdɑni ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹt. "fɝɡɪv mi, sɪɾɝ. siɪŋ əɹ soʊ sʌɾənli tʊk mi əbæk. wɛɹ wɑz aɪ? oʊ, jɛs. aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðət sɛlɪstɪn ən ænhɛɹiɾ ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn aʊɾ əɹ kloʊs fɹɛnz ɪn ðə jɛloʊ." sɛlɪstɪn ən ænhɛɹid wɝ maɪdɑniz fɛloʊ kənspɪɹəɾɝz, boʊθ jɛloʊ. ðəɹ wɝ tu fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ-ɪksɛp ðə ɹɛɾ ən ðə blu, ʌv kɔɹs-wɪtʃ hæd pɹuvən vɛɹi jusfəl "aɪ fɪɹ ðət woʊn bi mʌtʃ hɛlp. ʃiz ə waɪd sɝkəl ə fɹɛnz, əɹ dɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə... kɝən sɪtʃueɪʃən ɹoʊz bɪtwin ði ədʒəz." ə tʌtʃ ə sæɾəsfækʃən tɪŋd əɹ vɔɪs, haʊɛvɝ smuð əɹ feɪs; ʃi wɑz stɪl ə ɹɛbəl, ɪn spaɪɾ ə ði æɾəd oʊθ.

Suddenly, Yukiri realized that the wide, curving corridor was empty ahead as far as she could see, and a glance back showed only Leonin behind. The Tower might have been empty save of the three of them. Nothing in sight moved except the flickering flames on the stand lamps. Silence. Meidani gave a small start. "Forgive me, Sitter. Seeing her so suddenly took me aback. Where was I? Oh, yes. I understand that Celestin and Annharid are trying to find out her close friends in the Yellow." Celestin and Annharid were Meidani's fellow conspirators, both Yellow. There were two from each Ajah-except the Red and the Blue, of course-which had proven very useful "I fear that won't be much help. She has a wide circle of friends, or did before the... current situation rose between the Ajahs." A touch of satisfaction tinged her voice, however smooth her face; she was still a rebel, in spite of the added oath.

"ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾɪŋ ɔl ə ðɛm wɪl bi dɪfəkəlt, ɪf nɑɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl."

"Investigating all of them will be difficult, if not impossible."

"fɝɡɛɾ əɹ fəɹ ðə moʊmənt." ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt fəɹ jukɪɝi nɑt tə kɹeɪn əɹ nɛk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi weɪ ət wʌns. ə tæpəstʃɹi wɝkt wɪð lɑɹdʒ waɪt flaʊɝz ɹɪpəl slaɪtli, ən ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əntɪl ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹæft ən nɑɾ ənʌðɝ sɝvən kʌmɪŋ əɹ ʌv ə sɝvəns ɹæmp. ʃi nɛvɝ kəd ɹɛkəlɛkt wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ loʊkeɪɾəd. hɝ nu tɑpɪk wɑz əz deɪnʒɝəs əz dɪskʌsɪŋ əɾəən, ɪn ɪts oʊn weɪ.

"Forget her for the moment." It took an effort for Yukiri not to crane her neck trying to look every way at once. A tapestry worked with large white flowers rippled slightly, and she hesitated until she was sure it was a draft and not another servant coming our of a servant's ramp. She never could recollect where they were located. Her new topic was as dangerous as discussing Atuan, in its own way.

"læs naɪt, aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd jə wɝ ə nɑvəs wɪð ɪleɪɾə, ən kloʊs fɹɛnz əz aɪ ɹikɔl ɪt wəd bi ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə fəɹ jə tə ɹɪnu ðət fɹɛndʃɪp.'

"Last night, I remembered you were a novice with Elaida, and close friends as I recall It would be a good idea for you to renew that friendship.'

"ðæt wɑz səm jɪɹz əɡoʊ," ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd stɪfli, lɪftɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ən ɹæpɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf əz tʃ ʃi sʌɾənli fɛl ðə koʊld. "ɪleɪɾə vɛɹi pɹɑpɝli bɹoʊk ɪɾ ɔf wən ʃi wɑz ɹeɪzd æksɛptɪd. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn əkjuzd ə feɪvɝɪtɪzəm ɪf aɪ wɝ ɪn ə klæs ʃi wɑz ɡɪvən tə titʃ."

"That was some years ago," the taller woman replied stiffly, lifting her shawl to her shoulders and wrapping it around herself as chough she suddenly felt the cold. "Elaida very properly broke it off when she was raised Accepted. She might have been accused of favoritism if I were in a class she was given to teach."

"æz wɛl fəɹ jə ðət jə wɝn ə feɪvɹɪt," jukɪɝi sɛd dʒɹaɪli. ɪleɪɾəz kɝən fɝɑsəɾi hæɾ ɪts pɹɛsɪɾənt. bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɛn ɔf tə ændɝ jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ʃi hæd pʊʃt ðoʊz ʃi feɪvɝd soʊ hɑɹd ðət sɪstɝz hæd niɾəd tə stɛp ɪn mɔɹ ðən wʌns. sɪuən sɑntʃ hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðɛm, stʃɹeɪnʒ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðoʊ sɪuən hæd nɛvɝ niɾəd ɹɛskjuɪŋ fɹəm stændɝdz ʃi kəd nɑt mit. stʃɹeɪnʒ ən sæd. "ivən soʊ, jəl də ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn jəɹ paʊɝ tə ɹɪnu ðət fɹɛndʃɪp."

"As well for you that you weren't a favorite," Yukiri said dryly. Elaida's current ferocity had its precedent. Before she went off to Andor years ago, she had pushed those she favored so hard that sisters had needed to step in more than once. Siuan Sanche had been one of them, strange to remember, though Siuan had never needed rescuing from standards she could not meet. Strange and sad. "Even so, you will do everything in your power to renew that friendship."

maɪdɑni wɔk tu dʌzən peɪsɪz əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ əɹ maʊθ, ədʒʌstɪŋ ən ɹiədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl, twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃɹʌɡ ɔf ə hɔɹsfli, lʊkɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ bʌɾ ət jukɪɝi. haʊ hæd ðə wʊmən ɛvɝ fʌŋkʃən əz ə ɡɹeɪ wɪð soʊ lɪɾəl sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl? "aɪ dɪd tʃɹaɪ," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, ɪn ə bɹɛθi toʊn. ʃi stɪl əvɔɪɾəd jukɪɝi ɛs aɪ." sɛvɹəl taɪmz. ðə kipɝ . .

Meidani walked two dozen paces along the corridor opening and closing her mouth, adjusting and readjusting her shawl, twitching her shoulders as though trying to shrug off a horsefly, looking everywhere but at Yukiri. How had the woman ever functioned as a Gray with so little self-control? "I did try," she said finally, in a breathy tone. She still avoided Yukiri s eye." Several times. The Keeper . .

. ɑlviɛɝɪn ɔlweɪz pʊt mi ɔf. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz bɪzi, ʃi hæɾ əpɔɪnmənts, ʃi niɾəd ɹɛst. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz səm ɪkskjus. aɪ tʃɪŋk ɪleɪɾə dʒʌs dʌznt wɑnə teɪk ʌp ə fɹɛndʃɪp ʃi dʒɹɑp mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi jɪɹz əɡoʊ."

. Alviarin always put me off. The Amyrlin was busy, she had appointments, she needed rest. There was always some excuse. I chink Elaida just doesn't want to take up a friendship she dropped more than thirty years ago."

soʊ ðə ɹɛbəlz hæd ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət fɹɛndʃɪp, tu. haʊ hæd ðeɪ θɔt tə juz ɪt? spaɪɪŋ, moʊs laɪkli. ʃi wəɾ əv tə mɪɾ aʊt haʊ maɪdɑni wɑz səpoʊz tə pæs ɑn wʌt ʃi lɝnd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə ɹɛbəlz hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd ðə tul, ən jukɪɝi wəd juz ɪt. "ɑlviɛɝɪn ɪz aʊɾ ə jəɹ weɪ. ʃi lɛf ðə taʊɝ jɛstɝdeɪ, əɹ meɪbi ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ. noʊ wʌn ɪz kwaɪt sɝɾən. bʌt ðə meɪdz seɪ ʃi tʊk spɛɹ kloʊðz, soʊ ɪts ənlaɪkli ʃɪl ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ə fju deɪz ət ðə sunəst."

So the rebels had remembered that friendship, too. How had they thought to use it? Spying, most likely. She would have to mid out how Meidani was supposed to pass on what she learned. In any case, the rebels had provided the tool, and Yukiri would use it. "Alviarin is out of your way. She left the Tower yesterday, or maybe the day before. No one is quite certain. But the maids say she took spare clothes, so it's unlikely she'll return for a few days at the soonest."

"wɛɹ kəd ʃi hæv ɡɔn ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ?" maɪdɑni fɹaʊnd. "ɪts bɪn snoʊɪŋ sɪns jɛstɝdeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ɪt wɑz θɹɛɾənɪŋ bɪfɔɹ."

"Where could she have gone in this weather?" Meidani frowned. "It's been snowing since yesterday morning, and it was threatening before."

jukɪɝi stɑpt ən juz boʊθ hænz tə tɝn ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tə feɪs hɝ. "ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət nid kənsɝn ju, maɪdɑni, ɪz ðət ʃiz ɡɔn," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. wɛɹ hæɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn ɡɔn ɪn ðɪs? "ju hæv ə klɪɹ pæθ tə ɪleɪɾə, ən jəl teɪk ɪt. ən jəl kip ə kloʊs wɑtʃ tə si ɪf ɛni-wʌn maɪt bi ɹiɾɪŋ ɪleɪɾəz peɪpɝz, dʒʌs bi ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn siz jə wɑtʃɪŋ." tælin sɛd ðə blæk ədʒɑ nu ɛvɹi-θɪŋ ðət keɪm aʊɾ ə ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz ənaʊnst, ən ðeɪ niɾəd sʌmwʌn kloʊs tə ɪleɪɾə ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə faɪn aʊt haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn. ʌv kɔɹs, ɑlviɛɝɪn sɔ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪɾə saɪnd, ən ðə wʊmən hæd teɪkən ɑn mɔɹ əθɔɹəɾi ðən ɛni kipɝ ɪn mɛmɹi, bʌt ðət wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə əkjuz əɹ ə biɪŋ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. noʊ ɹizən nɑt tə, iðɝ. hɝ pæst wɑz biɪŋ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾəd, tu. "wɑtʃ ɑlviɛɝɪn, əz wɛl əz mʌtʃ əz jə kæn, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾəz peɪpɝz ɑɹ ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ." maɪdɑni saɪɾ ən ɡeɪv ə ɹɪlʌktənt nɑd. ʃi maɪɾ əv tə oʊbeɪ, bʌt ʃi nu ði æɾəd deɪnʒɝ ʃi wəd bi ɪn ɪf ɑlviɛɝɪn dɪd tɝn aʊɾ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. jɛɾ ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf stɪl maɪt bi blæk, wʌtɛvɝ sɹɪn ən pɛvɑɹə ɪnsɪstəd. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛn əz æmɪɝlɪn sit. naʊ ðət wɑz ə θɔt tə pɪkəl jəɹ hɑɹt.

Yukiri stopped and used both hands to turn the other woman to face her. "The only thing that need concern you, Meidani, is that she's gone," she said firmly. Where had Alviarin gone in this? "You have a clear path to Elaida, and you will take it. And you will keep a close watch to see if any-one might be reading Elaida's papers, just be sure no one sees you watching." Talene said the Black Ajah knew every-thing that came out of the Amyrlin's study before it was announced, and they needed someone close to Elaida if they were to find out how it was done. Of course, Alviarin saw everything before Elaida signed, and the woman had taken on more authority than any Keeper in memory, but that was no reason to accuse her of being a Darkfriend. No reason not to, either. Her past was being investigated, too. "Watch Alviarin, as well as much as you can, but Elaida's papers are the important thing." Meidani sighed and gave a reluctant nod. She might have to obey, but she knew the added danger she would be in if Alviarin did turn out a Darkfriend. Yet Elaida herself still might be Black, whatever Saerin and Pevara insisted. A Darkfriend as Amyrlin Seat. Now that was a thought to pickle your heart.

"jukɪɝi!" ə wʊmənz vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm bæk ʌp ðə hɔlweɪ. eɪ sɪɾɝ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ dɪd nɑt dʒʌmp laɪk ə stɑɹɾəld ɡoʊɾ ət hɪɹɪŋ əɹ oʊn neɪm, bʌt jukɪɝi dɪd. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn hoʊldɪŋ ɑntu maɪdɑni, ʃi maɪɾ əv fɔlən, ən əz ɪt wɑz, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm stæɡɝd laɪk dʒɹʌŋkən fɑɹmɝz əɾ ə hɑɹvəs dæns.

"Yukiri!" a woman's voice called from back up the hallway. A Sitter in the Hall of the Tower did not jump like a startled goat at hearing her own name, but Yukiri did. If she had not been holding onto Meidani, she might have fallen, and as it was, the pair of them staggered like drunken farmers at a harvest dance.

ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ, jukɪɝi dʒɝkt əɹ ʃɔl stʃɹeɪɾ ən sɛɾ əɹ feɪs ɪn ə skaʊl ðət dɪd nɑt dɪmɪnɪʃ wən ʃi sɔ hu wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd hɝ. sin wɑz səpoʊz tə bi kipɪŋ kloʊz tə hɝ oʊn ɹumz, wɪð əz mɛni waɪt sɪstɝz ɝaʊn əɹ əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ, wən ʃi wɑz nɑt wɪð jukɪɝi əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɪɾɝz u nu əbaʊt tælin ən ðə blæk ədʒɑ, bʌt hɪɹ ʃi wɑz skɝiɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ wɪð oʊnli bɝneɪl ɡɛlbɑɹn, ə stɑki tæɹɑbənɝ ən ənʌðɝ ə maɪdɑniz dʒækdɔz, fəɹ kʌmpəni.

Recovering, Yukiri jerked her shawl straight and set her face in a scowl that did not diminish when she saw who was running toward her. Seaine was supposed to be keeping close to her own rooms, with as many White sisters around her as she could manage, when she was not with Yukiri or one of the other Sitters who knew about Talene and the Black Ajah, but here she was scurrying down the hallway with only Bernaile Gelbarn, a stocky Taraboner and another of Meidani's jackdaws, for company.

lɛoʊnɪn stɛpt əsaɪd, ən ɡeɪv sin ə fɔɹməl baʊ, fɪŋɡɝtɪps pɹɛs tə hɪz hɑɹt. maɪdɑni ən bɝneɪl wɝ fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ smaɪlz. ðeɪ wɝ fɹɛnz, bʌt ðeɪ ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ, wən ðeɪ kəd nɑt tɛl u maɪt si.

Leonin stepped aside, and gave Seaine a formal bow, fingertips pressed to his heart. Meidani and Bernaile were foolish enough to exchange smiles. They were friends, but they should know better, when they could not tell who might see.

jukɪɝi wɑz ɪn noʊ mud fəɹ smaɪlz. "teɪkɪŋ ði ɛɹ, sin?" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "sɹɪn woʊn bi plizd, wən aɪ tɛl hɝ. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plizd. aɪm nɑt plizd, sin." maɪdɑni meɪɾ ə smɔl saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən bɝneɪlz hɛd twɪtʃt, hɝ mʌltətuɾ ə nɛɹoʊ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz ɹætlɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Yukiri was in no mood for smiles. "Taking the air, Seaine?" she said sharply. "Saerin won't be pleased, when I tell her. Not at all pleased. I'm not pleased, Seaine." Meidani made a small sound in her throat, and Bernaile's head twitched, her multitude of narrow beaded braids rattling against one another.

ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tʊk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ə tæpəstʃɹi ðət səpoʊzədli ʃoʊd ðə hʌmbəlɪŋ ə kwin ɹiænən, ən fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ smuð feɪsəz, klɪɹli ðeɪ wɪʃt ðeɪ wɝ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, sɪɾɝz wɝ səpoʊz tə bi ikwəlz. ən soʊ ðeɪ wɝ. nɔɹməli. æftɝ ə fæʃən. lɛoʊnɪn ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə hɪɹ ə wɝd, bʌɾ i kəd fil maɪdɑni ɛs mud, ʌv kɔɹs, ən i muvd ə stɛp fɝðɝ əweɪ. waɪl stɪl kipɪŋ wɑtʃ əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. ə ɡʊd mæn. ə waɪz mæn. sin hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə lʊk əbæʃt. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, ʃi smuðd əɹ dʒɹɛs, kʌvɝd wɪð snoʊi ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əlɔŋ ðə hɛm ən əkɹɔs ðə bɑɾəs, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli hɝ hænz nɑɾɪd ɪn əɹ ʃɔl ən əɹ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn stʌbɝnli. sin hæd bɪn stʃɹɔŋ-wɪl fɹəm ðə deɪ ʃi fɝs keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ, ə fɝnɪtʃɝ-meɪkɝz dɔɾɝ fɹəm luɡɹɾ u hæd tɔkt əɹ fɑðɝ ɪndə baɪɪŋ pæsədʒ fəɹ əɹ ən əɹ mʌðɝ.

The pair of them took to studying a tapestry that supposedly showed the humbling of Queen Rhiannon, and for all their smooth faces, clearly they wished they were somewhere else. In their eyes, Sitters were supposed to be equals. And so they were. Normally. After a fashion. Leonin should not have been able to hear a word, but he could feel Meidani s mood, of course, and he moved a step further away. While still keeping watch along the corridor, of course. A good man. A wise man. Seaine had sense enough to look abashed. Unconsciously, she smoothed her dress, covered with snowy embroidery along the hem and across the bodice, but almost immediately her hands knotted in her shawl and her eyebrows drew down stubbornly. Seaine had been strong-willed from the day she first came to the Tower, a furniture-maker's daughter from Lugard who had talked her father into buying passage for her and her mother.

pæsədʒ fəɹ tu ʌpɹɪvɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn daʊn. stʃɹɔŋ-wɪld ən kɑnfəɾənt. ən fɹikwənli əz blaɪn tə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn əɹ əz ɛni bɹaʊn. waɪts wɝ ɔfən laɪk ðæt, ɔl lɑdʒɪk ən noʊ dʒʌdʒmənt. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ mi tə haɪd fɹəm ðə blæk ədʒɑ, jukɪɝi," ʃi sɛd.

Passage for two upriver, but only one down. Strong-willed and confident. And frequently as blind to the world around her as any Brown. Whites were often like that, all logic and no judgment. "There's no need for me to hide from the Black Ajah, Yukiri," she said.

jukɪɝi wɪnst. ful wʊmən, neɪmɪŋ ðə blæk ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən. ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz stɪl ɛmpti ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz əz fɑɹ əz ðə kɝv əlaʊd saɪt, bʌt kɛɹləsnəs lɛd tə mɔɹ kɛɹləsnəs. ʃi kəd bi stʌbɝn hɝsɛlf, wən ðəɹ wɑz nid, bʌɾ ət list ʃi ʃoʊd mɔɹ bɹeɪn ðən ə ɡus əbaʊt wən ən wɛɹ. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɡɪv sin ə pis ə hɝ maɪnd, ə ʃɑɹp pis, bʌt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɹʌʃt ɑn bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik.

Yukiri winced. Fool woman, naming the Black right out in the open. The corridor was still empty in both directions as far as the curve allowed sight, but carelessness led to more carelessness. She could be stubborn herself, when there was need, but at least she showed more brain than a goose about when and where. She opened her mouth to give Seaine a piece of her mind, a sharp piece, but the other woman rushed on before she could speak.

"sɹɪn toʊl mi aɪ kəd faɪn ju." sinz maʊθ taɪɾənd ən spɑts ə kʌlɝ flɛɹɾ ɪn əɹ tʃiks, ət hævɪŋ æsk pɝmɪʃən əɹ ət hævɪŋ tə æsk. ɪt wɑz ʌndɝstændəbəl fəɹ əɹ tə ɹɪzɛn əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. dʒʌst wɪtləs fəɹ əɹ nɑt tə æksɛpt ɪt. aɪ nid tə tɔk tə jə əloʊn, jukɪɝi. əbaʊt ðə sɛkən mɪstɝi."

"Saerin told me I could find you." Seaine's mouth tightened and spots of color flared in her cheeks, at having asked permission or at having to ask. It was understandable for her to resent her situation, of course. Just witless for her not to accept it. I need to talk to you alone, Yukiri. About the second mystery."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, jukɪɝi wɑz əz pʌzəld əz maɪdɑni ən bɝneɪl lʊkt. ðeɪ kəd ʃæm nɑt lɪsnɪŋ, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt ʃʌt ðɛɹ ɪɹz. sɛkən mɪstɝi? wʌd sin min? ənlɛs . . . kəd ʃi min ðə θɪŋ ðət hæd bɹɔt jukɪɝi ɪndə ðə hʌn fəɹ ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs? wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ðə hɛdz ə ði ədʒəz wɝ miɾɪŋ ɪn sikɹət hæd lɔst ɪts ɝdʒənsi kəmpɛɹd tə faɪndɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz.

For a moment, Yukiri was as puzzled as Meidani and Bernaile looked. They could sham not listening, but that did not shut their ears. Second mystery? What did Seaine mean? Unless . . . Could she mean the thing that had brought Yukiri into the hunt for the Black Ajah in the first place? Wondering why the heads of the Ajahs were meeting in secret had lost its urgency compared to finding Darkfriends among the sisters.

"vɛɹi wɛl, sin," jukɪɝi sɛd, mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt. "maɪdɑni, teɪk lɛoʊnɪn daʊn ðə hɔl əntɪl jə kən dʒʌst si sin ən mi ɝaʊn ðə kɝv. kip ə ʃɑɹp aɪ fəɹ ɛniwʌn kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ.

"Very well, Seaine," Yukiri said, more calmly than she felt. "Meidani, take Leonin down the hall until you can just see Seaine and me around the curve. Keep a sharp eye for anyone coming this way.

bɝneɪl, də ðə seɪm ʌp ðə hɔl." ðeɪ wɝ muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ, ən əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪɹʃɑt, ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə sin. "wɛl?" tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ spɹæŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ðə waɪt sɪɾɝ, hu woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ə klɪɹ saɪn ə sikɹəts tə ɛni wʌn u sɔ. ðɪs hæd bɛɾɝ bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Bernaile, do the same up the hall." They were moving before she finished speaking, and as soon as they were out of earshot, she turned her attention to Seaine. "Well?" To her surprise, the glow of saidar sprang up around the White Sitter, who wove a ward against eavesdropping around the pair of them. It was a clear sign of secrets to any one who saw. This had better be important.

"θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt lɑdʒɪkli." sinz vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, bʌɾ əɹ hænz stɪl ɡɹɪpt əɹ ʃɔl ɪn fɪsts.

"Think about it logically." Seaine's voice was calm, but her hands still gripped her shawl in fists.

ʃi stʊd vɛɹi stʃɹeɪt, taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ jukɪɝi ðoʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ əbʌv ævɝɪdʒ haɪt hɝsɛlf.

She stood very straight, towering over Yukiri though she was not much above average height herself.

"ɪts mɔɹ ðən ə mʌnθ, ɔlmoʊs tu, sɪns ɪleɪɾə keɪm tə mi, ən nɪɹli tu wiks sɪns jə faʊn pɛvɑɹə ən mi. ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ nu əbaʊt mi, aɪ wəd bi dɛd baɪ naʊ. pɛvɑɹə ən aɪ wʊɾə bɪn dɛd bɪfɔɹ jə ən dʌsin ən sɹɪn ɛvɝ wɔkt ɪn ɑn ʌs, ðɛɹfɔɹ, ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ. əbaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ʌs. aɪ ədmɪɾ aɪ wɑz fɹaɪɾənd, ət fɝst, bʌɾ aɪ hæv kəntʃɹoʊl ə maɪsɛlf, naʊ. ðɛɹz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə jə tə kip tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃɹit mi laɪk ə nɑvəs," ə lɪɾəl hiɾ ɪnveɪɾəd ðə kɑmnəs, "æn ə bɹeɪnləs wʌn, ət ðæt."

"It's more than a month, almost two, since Elaida came to me, and nearly two weeks since you found Pevara and me. If the Black Ajah knew about me, I would be dead by now. Pevara and I would have been dead before you and Doesine and Saerin ever walked in on us, Therefore, they don't know. About any of us. I admit I was frightened, at first, but I have control of myself, now. There's no reason for the rest of you to keep trying to treat me like a novice," a little heat invaded the calmness, "and a brainless one, at that."

"jul əv tə tɔk tə sɹɪn," jukɪɝi sɛd kɝtli. sɹɪn hæd teɪkən tʃɑɹdʒ fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. æftɝ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz ɪn ðə hɔl fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn, sɹɪn wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət teɪkɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ ən jukɪɝi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ ənlɛs ʃi mʌst, nɑt wɪθaʊt ðə sɪɾɝz pɹɪvlədʒ ʃi kəd hɑɹdli kleɪm ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə kætʃ ə fɔlɪŋ boʊldɝ. ɪf sɹɪn kəd bi kənvɪnst, pɛvɑɹə ən dʌsin wəd kʌm ɝaʊnd, ən ʃi hɝsɛlf wəd hɑɹdli tʃɹaɪ tə stæn ɪn ðə weɪ. "naʊ, wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɪs sɛkən sikɹət? jə də min ði ədʒɑ hɛdz miɾɪŋ?"

"You'll have to talk to Saerin," Yukiri said curtly. Saerin had taken charge from the start. After forty years in the Hall for the Brown, Saerin was very good at taking charge and Yukiri had no intention of going against her unless she must, not without the Sitter's privilege she could hardly claim in the circumstances. As well try to catch a falling boulder. If Saerin could be convinced, Pevara and Doesine would come around, and she herself would hardly try to stand in the way. "Now, what about this second secret? You do mean the Ajah heads meeting?"

sinz feɪs tʊk ɑn ə mjuli ɪkspɹɛʃən. jukɪɝi ɔlmoʊst ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ ɪɹz tə laɪ bæk. ðən ʃi ɛksheɪld. "dɪd ðə hɛɾ ə jəɹ ədʒɑ hæv ə hæn ɪn tʃuzɪŋ ændaɪə fəɹ ðə hɔl? mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl, aɪ min?"

Seaine's face took on a muley expression. Yukiri almost expected her ears to lie back. Then she exhaled. "Did the head of your Ajah have a hand in choosing Andaya for the Hall? More than usual, I mean?"

"ʃi dɪd," jukɪɝi ɹɪplaɪd kɛɹfəli. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ændaɪə wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə hɔl wʌn deɪ pɝhæps ɪn ənʌðɝ fɔɹɾi əɹ fɪfti jɪɹz, jɛt sɹæntʃə hæɾ ɔl bʌɾ ənɔɪntəd hɝ, wən ðə kʌstəmɛɹi mɛθəd wɑz dɪskʌʃən əntɪl ə kənsɛnsəs kəɾ i ɹitʃt ɑn tu əɹ θɹi kændəɾeɪts, ðən ə sikɹət bælət. ðət wɑz ədʒɑ bɪznəs, ðoʊ, əz sikɹəɾ əz sɹæntʃəz neɪm ən taɪɾəl.

"She did," Yukiri replied carefully. Everyone had been sure Andaya would go into the Hall one day perhaps in another forty or fifty years, yet Serancha had all but anointed her, when the customary method was discussion until a consensus could he reached on two or three candidates, then a secret ballot. That was Ajah business, though, as secret as Serancha's name and title.

"aɪ nu ɪt." sin nɑɾəd ɪksaɪɾədli, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əɹ nɔɹməl mænɝ. "sɹɪn sɛz ðət dʒuleɪn wɑz hænd-pɪk fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn, tu, əpɛɹənli nɑt ðɛɹ juʒəwəl weɪ, ən dʌsin sɛz ðə seɪm əbaʊt swænə, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz hɛzɪɾənt əbaʊt seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. aɪ θɪŋk swænə meɪbi ðə hɛɾ ə ðə jɛloʊ hɝsɛlf. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi wɑz ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ fɔɹɾi jɪɹz ðə fɝs taɪm, ən jə noʊ ɪɾ ɪzən kɑmən tə teɪk ə tʃɛɹ æftɝ jə wɝ ə sɪɾɝ ðət lɔŋ. ən fɛɹən stɛp daʊn fəɹ ðə waɪt lɛs ðən tɛn jɪɹz əɡoʊ; noʊ wʌn əz ɛvɝ ɛntɝd ðə hɔl əɡɛn soʊ sun. tə kæp ɪɾ ɔf, tælin sɛz ðə ɡɹinz nɑmənət tʃɔɪsəz ən ðɛɹ kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl tʃuzəz wʌn, bʌɾ ædlɔɹnə tʃoʊz ɹinə wɪθaʊɾ ɛni nɑməneɪʃənz." jukɪɝi mænədʒ tə staɪfəl ə ɡɹɪmɑs, bʌɾ oʊnli baɪ ə hɛɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd ðɛɹ səspɪʃənz əbaʊɾ u hɛɾəd ʌðɝ ədʒəz, ɛls noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ əv noʊɾəst ðə miɾɪŋz ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, jɛt spikɪŋ ðoʊz neɪmz əlaʊd wɑz ɹuɾ ət bɛst. ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ə sɪɾɝ maɪt feɪs pɛnəns fəɹ ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi ən sin boʊθ nu wən ɪt keɪm tə ædlɔɹnə. ɪn əɹ ətɛmps tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ, tælin pɔɹɾ əɹ ɔl ðə sikɹəts ə ðə ɡɹin wɪθaʊt biɪŋ æskt. ɪɾ ɪmbɛɹəst ɔl ə ðɛm, ɪksɛp tælin hɝsɛlf. ət list ɪɾ ɪkspleɪnd waɪ ðə ɡɹinz hæd bɪn ɪn sətʃ ən aʊtstændɪŋ ɹeɪdʒ wən ædlɔɹnə wɑz bɝtʃt. stɪl, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl wɑz ə ɹɪdɪkjələs taɪɾəl, bæɾəl ədʒɑ əɹ noʊ bæɾəl ədʒɑ. ət lis hɛd klɝk ɹɪli dɪskɹaɪbd wʌt sɹæntʃə dɪd, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, maɪdɑni ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ wɝ stændɪŋ dʒʌst ɪn saɪɾ ɑn ðə kɝv, əpɛɹənli tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli. wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ ɔlweɪz wɑtʃt fɝðɝ daʊn ɝaʊn ðə kɝv, ðoʊ. ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən, bɝneɪl wɑz dʒʌst ɪn saɪt, tu. hɝ hɛd wɑz swɪvəlɪŋ kɑnstənli əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə wɑtʃ jukɪɝi ən sin waɪl kipɪŋ ən aɪ aʊt fəɹ ɛniwʌn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ. ðə weɪ ʃi kɛpt ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm wʌn fʊt tə ði ʌðɝ wəɾ ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən, tu, bʌt ðiz deɪz ə sɪstɝ əloʊn aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝ wɑz æskɪŋ fəɹ tʃɹʌbəl, ən ʃi nu ɪt. ðɪs kɑnvɝseɪʃən hæd tə ɛn sun.

"I knew it." Seaine nodded excitedly, not at all her normal manner. "Saerin says that Juilaine was hand-picked for the Brown, too, apparently not their usual way, and Doesine says the same about Suana, though she was hesitant about saying anything. I think Suana maybe the head of the Yellow herself. In any case, she was a Sitter for forty years the first time, and you know it isn't common to take a chair after you were a Sitter that long. And Ferane stepped down for the White less than ten years ago; no one has ever entered the Hall again so soon. To cap it off, Talene says the Greens nominate choices and their Captain-General chooses one, but Adelorna chose Rina without any nominations." Yukiri managed to stifle a grimace, but only by a hair. Everyone had their suspicions about who headed other Ajahs, else no one would ever have noticed the meetings in the first place, yet speaking those names aloud was rude at best. Anyone but a Sitter might face penance for it. Of course, she and Seaine both knew when it came to Adelorna. In her attempts to curry favor, Talene poured our all the secrets of the Green without being asked. It embarrassed all of them, except Talene herself. At least it explained why the Greens had been in such an outstanding rage when Adelorna was birched. Still, Captain-General was a ridiculous title, Battle Ajah or no Battle Ajah. At least Head Clerk really described what Serancha did, in a manner of speaking. Down the corridor, Meidani and her Warder were standing just in sight on the curve, apparently talking quietly. One or the other always watched further down around the curve, though. In the opposite direction, Bernaile was just in sight, too. Her head was swiveling constantly as she tried to watch Yukiri and Seaine while keeping an eye out for anyone approaching. The way she kept shifting from one foot to the other would attract attention, too, but these days a sister alone outside her Ajah quarter was asking for trouble, and she knew it. This conversation had to end soon.

jukɪɝi ɹeɪzd wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. "faɪv ədʒəz hæd tə tʃuz nu sɪɾɝz æftɝ wɪmən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ðə hɔl dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛbəlz.' sin nɑɾəd, ən jukɪɝi ɹeɪzd ə sɛkən fɪŋɡɝ. "itʃ ə ðoʊz ədʒəz tʃoʊz ə wʊmən əz sɪɾɝ u wɑzn ðə . . . lɑdʒɪkəl... tʃɔɪs." sin nɑɾəd əɡɛn. ə θɝd ɹɪŋɝ dʒɔɪn ðə fɝs tu. "ðə bɹaʊn hæd tə tʃuz tu nu sɪɾɝz, bʌt jə dɪdn mɛnʃən ʃɛvən. ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ..." jukɪɝi smaɪld ɹaɪli, "ɑd . . . əbaʊt hɝ?"

Yukiri raised one finger. "Five Ajahs had to choose new Sitters after women they had in the Hall joined the rebels.' Seaine nodded, and Yukiri raised a second finger. "Each of those Ajahs chose a woman as Sitter who wasn't the . . . logical... choice." Seaine nodded again. A third ringer joined the first two. "The Brown had to choose two new Sitters, but you didn't mention Shevan. Is there anything..." Yukiri smiled wryly, "odd . . . about her?"

"noʊ; əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə sɹɪn, ʃɛvən wəd laɪkli hæv bɪn əɹ ɹɪpleɪsmənt: wən ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stɛp daʊn, bʌt-"

"No; according to Saerin, Shevan would likely have been her replacement: when she decided to step down, but-"

"sin, ɪf jəɹ æktʃəli  ɪmplaɪɪŋ ði ədʒɑ hɛdz kənspaɪɝɾ oʊvɝ u wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə hɔl-æn aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə mɔɹ kɹækt-bɹeɪnd noʊʃən! -ɪf ðæts wʌt jəɹ sədʒɛstɪŋ, waɪ wəd ðeɪ tʃuz faɪv ɑd wɪmən ən wʌn u ɪzənt?'

"Seaine, if you're actually implying the Ajah heads conspired over who would go into the Hall-and I never heard of a more cracked-brained notion! -If that's what you're suggesting, why would they choose five odd women and one who isn't?'
