"jɛs, aɪm sədʒɛstɪŋ ɪt. wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə jə kipɪŋ mi pɹæktəkli ʌndɝ lɑk ən ki, aɪv hæd mɔɹ taɪm fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ðən aɪ noʊ wʌt tə də wɪð. dʒuleɪn ən ɹinə ən ændaɪə ɡeɪv mi ə hɪnt, ən fɛɹən meɪd mi dɪsaɪd tə tʃɛk." wʌd sin min əbaʊɾ ændaɪə ən ði ʌðɝ tu ɡɪvɪŋ ə hɪnt? oʊ. ʌv kɔɹs; ɹinə ən ændaɪə wɝ nɑt ɹɪli oʊld ɪnʌf tə hi ɪn ðə hɔl jɛt, iðɝ. ðə kʌstəm ə nɑt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ eɪdʒ sun ɪnʌf bɪkeɪm ðə hæbəɾ ə nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, iðɝ.

"Yes, I am suggesting it. With the rest of you keeping me practically under lock and key, I've had more time for thinking than I know what to do with. Juilaine and Rina and Andaya gave me a hint, and Ferane made me decide to check." What did Seaine mean about Andaya and the other two giving a hint? Oh. Of course; Rina and Andaya were not really old enough to he in the Hall yet, either. The custom of not talking about age soon enough became the habit of not thinking about it, either.

"tu maɪɾ əv bɪn koʊɪnsɪɾəns," sin wɛn ɑn, "ivən θɹi, ðoʊ ðət stʃɹeɪnz kɹɪduləɾi, bʌt faɪv meɪks ə pæɾɝn. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə blu, ðə bɹaʊn wɑz ði oʊnli ədʒɑ tə hæv tu sɪɾɝz dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛbəlz. meɪbi ðɛɹz ə ɹizən ɪn ðət waɪ ðeɪ tʃoʊz wʌn ɑd sɪstɝ ən wʌn nɑt, ɪf aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊt.

"Two might have been coincidence," Seaine went on, "even three, though that strains credulity, but five makes a pattern. Except for the Blue, the Brown was the only Ajah to have two Sitters join the rebels. Maybe there's a reason in that why they chose one odd sister and one not, if I can figure it out.

bʌt ðəɹ ɪz ə pæɾɝn, jukɪɝi-ə pʌzəl-ænd wɛðɝ ɪts ɹæʃənəl əɹ nɑt, sʌmθɪŋ tɛlz mi wi hæd bɛɾɝ sɑlv ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛbəlz ɡɛt hɪɹ. ɪt meɪks mi fil əz ðoʊ sʌm-bɑɾiz hæn ɪz ɑn maɪ ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt wən aɪ lʊk, ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniwʌn ðɛɹ."

But there is a pattern, Yukiri-a puzzle-and whether it's rational or not, something tells me we had better solve it before the rebels get here. It makes me feel as though some-body's hand is on my shoulder, but when I look, there isn't anyone there."

wʌt stʃɹeɪn kɹɪduləɾi wɑz ði aɪdiə ʌv ði ədʒɑ hɛdz kənspaɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. bʌt ðɛn, jukɪɝi θɔt, ə kənspɪɹəsi ʌv sɪɾɝz ɪz bɪɑn fɑɹ-fɛtʃt, ən aɪm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wʌn. ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə sɪmpəl fæk ðət noʊ wʌn aʊtsaɪɾ ən ədʒɑ wɑz səpoʊz tə noʊ ði ədʒɑz hɛd, bʌt ði ʌðɝ ədʒɑ hɛdz əɡɛnst ɔl kʌstəm dɪd. "ɪf ðɛɹz ə pʌzəl" ʃi sɛd wɛɹəli, "ju hæv ə lɔŋ taɪm tə sɑlv ɪt. ðə ɹɛbəlz kæn liv mʊɹændi bɪfɔɹ spɹɪŋ, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪv toʊl pipəl, ən ðə mɑɹtʃ ʌpɹɪvɝ wɪl teɪk mʌnθs, ɪf ðeɪ hoʊl ðɛɹ ɑɹmi təɡɛðɝ ðət lɔŋ." ʃi dɪd nɑt daʊt ðeɪ wʊd, ðoʊ, nɑɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. "ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ ɹumz bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn siz əs stændɪŋ hɪɹ wɔɹɾɪd, ən θɪŋk ɑn jəɹ pʌzəl," ʃi sɛd, nɑɾ əŋkinli, ɹɛstɪŋ ə hæn ɑn sinz sliv. "jul əv tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð biɪŋ lʊkt æftɝ əntɪl wɝ ɔl ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ seɪf."

What strained credulity was the idea of the Ajah heads conspiring in the first place. But then, Yukiri thought, a conspiracy of Sitters is beyond far-fetched, and I'm in the middle of one. And there was the simple fact that no one outside an Ajah was supposed to know the Ajah's head, but the other Ajah heads against all custom did. "If there's a puzzle" she said wearily, "you have a long time to solve it. The rebels can't leave Murandy before spring, whatever they've told people, and the march upriver will take months, if they hold their army together that long." She did not doubt they would, though, not any longer. "Go back to your rooms before someone sees us standing here warded, and think on your puzzle," she said, not unkindly, resting a hand on Seaine's sleeve. "You'll have to put up with being looked after until we're all sure you are safe."

ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn sinz feɪs wʊɾə bɪn kɔl sʌlən ɑn ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ə sɪɾɝ. "aɪl spik tə sɹɪn əɡɛn," ʃi sɛd, bʌt ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɝaʊn əɹ vænɪʃt.

The expression on Seaine's face would have been called sullen on anyone but a Sitter. "I'll speak to Saerin again," she said, but the light of saidar around her vanished.

wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ dʒɔɪn bɝneɪl ən ðə tu ʌv əm ɡlaɪɾ ʌp ðə kɝvɪŋ hɔlweɪ təwɔɹd ði ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz; boʊθ əz wɛɹi əz fɔnz wən wʊlvz wɝ aʊt, jukɪɝi fɛlt ə hɛvi hɑɹt. ɪt wɑz ə pɪɾi ðə ɹɛbəlz kəd nɑt ɡɛt ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ sʌmɝ. ət lis ðət maɪt meɪk ði ədʒəz kʌm təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, soʊ sɪstɝz wɝ nɑt fɔɹs tə slɪŋk əbaʊt ðə waɪt taʊɝ. əz wɛl wɪʃ fəɹ wɪŋz, ʃi θɔt sædli.

Watching her join Bernaile and the two of them glide up the curving hallway toward the Ajah quarters; both as wary as fawns when wolves were out, Yukiri felt a heavy heart. It was a pity the rebels could not get there before summer. At least that might make the Ajahs come together again, so sisters were not forced to slink about the White Tower. As well wish for wings, she thought sadly.

dɪtɝmən tə kip əɹ muɾ ɪn tʃɛk, ʃi wɛn tə ɡæðɝ ʌp maɪdɑni ən lɛoʊnɪn. ʃi hæɾ ə blæk sɪstɝ tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt, ən ət list ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən wɑz ə pʌzəl ʃi nu haʊ tə wɝk.

Determined to keep her mood in check, she went to gather up Meidani and Leonin. She had a Black sister to investigate, and at least investigation was a puzzle she knew how to work.

ɡɔɪnz aɪz pɑpt oʊpən ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs əz ə nu weɪv ə koʊld ɹoʊz ɪndə ðə heɪlɔft. ðə bɑɹnz θɪk stoʊnwɔlz nɔɹməli kɛpt aʊt ðə wɝst ə ðə naɪts tʃɪl, ɪf oʊnli ðə wɝst. vɔɪsəz mɝmɝd bɪloʊ; noʊ wʌn saʊndəɾ ɪksaɪɾəd. hi tʊk ɪz hæn əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɔɹd laɪɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ən tʌɡd ɪz ɡɔnləts taɪɾɝ. laɪk ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz, hi slɛpt ɪn ɛvɹi stɪtʃ i kəd pʊɾ ɑn. pɹɑbli ɪt wɑz dʒʌs taɪm tə weɪk səm ə ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ sɛntʃɹi tɝnz, bʌɾ i wɑz fʊli əweɪk naʊ hɪmsɛlf ən i daʊɾɪd i wəd faɪn slip əɡɛn sun. ɪn ɛni keɪs, hɪz slip wɑz ɔlweɪz fɹɛtfəl tʃɹʌbəl baɪ dɑɹk dʒɹimz, hɔntəd baɪ ðə wʊmən i lʌvd. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ɛɡwin wɑz, əɹ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz əlaɪv.

Gawyn's eyes popped open in the darkness as a new wave of cold rose into the hayloft. The barn's thick stonewalls normally kept out the worst of the nights chill, if only the worst. Voices murmured below; no one sounded excited. He took his hand away from the sword lying beside him and tugged his gauntlets tighter. Like all the rest of the Younglings, he slept in every stitch he could put on. Probably it was just time to wake some of the men around him for their sentry turns, but he was fully awake now himself and he doubted he would find sleep again soon. In any case, his sleep was always fretful troubled by dark dreams, haunted by the woman he loved. He did not know where Egwene was, or whether she was alive.

əɹ wɛðɝ ʃi kəd fɝɡɪv hɪm. hi stʊɾ ʌp; lɛɾɪŋ ðə lus heɪ hi hæd pʊld oʊvɝ hɪmsɛlf slaɪɾ ɔf ɪz kloʊk, ən bʌkəld ɑn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt.

Or whether she could forgive him. He stood up; letting the loose hay he had pulled over himself slide off his cloak, and buckled on his sword belt.

əz i pɪkt ɪz weɪ əmʌŋ ðə ʃæɾoʊi maʊnz ə mɛn slipɪŋ ətɑp ðə stæk beɪlz ə heɪ, ðə feɪn skɹeɪp ə buts ɑn wʊɾən ɹʌŋz toʊld ɪm sʌmwʌn wɑz klaɪmɪŋ ðə læɾɝ tə ðə lɔft. ə dɪm fɪɡjɝ əpɪɹɾ ət ðə tɑp ə ðə læɾɝ, ðən stɑp tə weɪt fəɹ hɪm.

As he picked his way among the shadowy mounds of men sleeping atop the stacked bales of hay, the faint scrape of boots on wooden rungs told him someone was climbing the ladder to the loft. A dim figure appeared at the top of the ladder, then stopped to wait for him.

"lɔɹd ɡɔɪn!" ɹeɪjɹz dip vɔɪs sɛd sɔfli ɪn ə dəmɑni æksɛn ənɔltɝd baɪ sɪks jɪɹz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðə fɝs lutɛnəns ɹʌmbəlɪŋ vɔɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz ə sɝpɹaɪz, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə slaɪt mæn u stʊd bɛɹli haɪɝ ðən ɡɔɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. ivən soʊ, hæd taɪmz bɪn dɪfɹənt, ɹeɪjɹ ʃʊɹli wʊɾə bɪn ə wɔɹɾɝ baɪ ðɪs taɪm. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪɾ əv tə weɪk ju. ə sɪstɝ dʒʌst ɝaɪvd, ɑn fʊt. ə mɛsənʒɝ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, ʃi wɑntəd ðə sɪstɝ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ hɪɹ. aɪ toʊl tɑməl ən ɪz bɹʌðɝ tə teɪk əɹ tə ðə meɪɝz haʊs bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tɝn ɪn fəɹ ðə naɪt."

"Lord Gawyn!" Rajar's deep voice said softly in a Domani accent unaltered by six years training in Tar Valon. The First Lieutenant's rumbling voice was always a surprise, coming from a slight man who stood barely higher than Gawyn's shoulder. Even so, had times been different, Rajar surely would have been a Warder by this time. "I thought I'd have to wake you. A sister just arrived, on foot. A messenger from the Tower, She wanted the sister in charge here. I told Tomil and his brother to take her to the Mayor's house before they turned in for the night."

ɡɔɪn saɪd. hi ʃʊɾə ɡɔn hoʊm wən i ɹɪtɝn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən faʊn ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz ɪkspɛl fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ɪnstɛɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bi kɑt hɪɹ baɪ wɪntɝ. ɪspɛʃli wən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪleɪɾə wɑntəɾ əm ɔl dɛd. hɪz sɪstɝ ɪleɪn wəd kʌm tə keɪməln ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪf ʃi wɑz nɔɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. sɝɾənti ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd si ðət ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn ɪn taɪm tə kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn bɪfɔɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls kʊd. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wəd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp ði ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ə kwin u wəɾ ɔlsoʊ bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ɪleɪn kəd bi ɑn əɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, tu, əɹ ɹɪzaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɹaɪt ðət mɪnət. hi dɪd nɔɹ haʊ ʃi hæd bɪkʌm ɛntæŋɡəld wɪð sɪuən sɑntʃ, əɹ haʊ dipli-ʃi ɔlweɪz dʌv ɪndə ə pɑnd wɪθaʊt tʃɛkɪŋ ðə dɛpθ-bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə ən ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ maɪt wɑnə kwɛstʃən əɹ kloʊsli, dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɹ nɑt. kwin əɹ nɑt. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd nɑt bi hɛld əkaʊntəbəl, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz stɪl oʊnli wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd. hi hæd tə tɛl hɪmsɛlf ðət fɹikwənli.

Gawyn sighed. He should have gone home when he returned to Tar Valon and found the Younglings expelled from the city, instead of letting himself be caught here by winter. Especially when he was sure Elaida wanted them all dead. His sister Elayne would come to Caemyln eventually, if she was nor already there. Certainty any Aes Sedai would see that the Daughter-Heir of Andor reached Caemlyn in time to claim the throne before someone else could. The White Tower would not give up the advantage of a queen who would also be Aes Sedai. On the other hand, Elayne could be on her way to Tar Valon, too, or residing in the White Tower right that minute. He did nor how she had become entangled with Siuan Sanche, or how deeply-she always dove into a pond without checking the depth-but Elaida and the Hall of the Tower might want to question her closely, Daughter-Heir or not. Queen or not. He was sure she could not be held accountable, though. She was still only one of the Accepted. He had to tell himself that frequently.

ðə nuəs pɹɑbləm wɑz ðəɾ ən ɑɹmi leɪ bɪtwin ɪm ən tɑɹ vəlɑn, naʊ. ət lis twɛnti-faɪv θaʊzən soʊlʒɝz ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn ænd, hi hæd tə bɪliv, əz mɛni ɑn ðə wɛs bæŋk. ðeɪ hæd tə bi səpɔɹɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɪleɪɾə kɔld ɹɛbəlz. hu ɛls wəd dɛɹ bɪsidʒ tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf? ðə weɪ ðəɾ ɑɹmi hæɾ əpɪɹd, ðoʊ, simɪŋ tə mətɪɹiəlaɪz aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə snoʊstɔɹm, wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɹeɪz pɹɪkəlz ɑn ɪz bæk stɪl. ɹumɝ ən əlɑɹmz ɔlweɪz flu əhɛɾ ʌv ɛni lɑɹdʒ fɔɹs ʌndɝ ɑɹmz ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ. ɔlweɪz. ðɪs wʌn hæɾ ɝaɪv laɪk spɪɹəts, ɪn saɪləns. ði ɑɹmi wɑz əz ɹil əz stoʊn, haʊɛvɝ, soʊ hi kəd niðɝ ɛntɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn tə faɪnd wɛðɝ ɪleɪn wɑz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, nɔɹ ɹaɪd saʊθ. ɛni ɑɹmi wəd teɪk noʊɾəs ʌv ʌpwɝdz ə θɹi hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɑn ðə muv, ən ðə ɹɛbəlz wəɾ əv noʊ ɡʊd wɪl təwɔɹd ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. ivən ɪf i wɛn əloʊn, tʃɹævəl ɪn wɪntɝ wɑz vɛɹi sloʊ, ən i kəd ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn əz kwɪkli ɪf i weɪɾəd əntɪl spɹɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hoʊp ə faɪndɪŋ pæsədʒ ɑn ə ʃɪp, iðɝ. ðə sidʒ wəd maɪɹ ɹɪvɝ tʃɹæfɪk ɪn ə hoʊpləs snɑɹl. hi wɑz maɪɹɾ ɪn ə hoʊpləs snɑɹl.

The newest problem was that an army lay between him and Tar Valon, now. At least twenty-five thousand soldiers on this side of the River Erinin and, he had to believe, as many on the west bank. They had to be supporting the Aes Sedai who Elaida called rebels. Who else would dare besiege Tar Valon itself? The way that army had appeared, though, seeming to materialize out of nowhere in the middle of a snowstorm, was enough to raise prickles on his back still. Rumor and alarms always flew ahead of any large force under arms on the march. Always. This one had arrived like spirits, in silence. The army was as real as stone, however, so he could neither enter Tar Valon to find whether Elayne was in the Tower, nor ride south. Any army would take notice of upwards of three hundred men on the move, and the rebels would have no good will toward the Younglings. Even if he went alone, travel in winter was very slow, and he could reach Caemlyn as quickly if he waited until spring. There was no hope of finding passage on a ship, either. The siege would mire river traffic in a hopeless snarl. He was mired in a hopeless snarl.

ən naʊ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd kʌm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt. ʃi wəd nɑt sɪmpləfaɪ mæɾɝz ɛni.

And now an Aes Sedai had come in the middle of the night. She would not simplify matters any.

"lɛts faɪn əɹ wʌt nuz ʃi bɹɔt," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, moʊʃənɪŋ ɹeɪjɹ daʊn ðə læɾɝ əhɛɾ ə hɪm, twɛnti hɔɹsəz ən ðɛɹ stæk sæɾəlz kɹaʊɾəd nɪɹli ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə ðə dɑɹk bɑɹn nɔɹ teɪkən baɪ mɪstʃɹəs mɪlənz tu dʌzən əɹ soʊ mɪlk kaʊz ɪn ðɛɹ stɔlz, soʊ hi ən ɹeɪjɹ hæd tə θɹɛd ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə waɪd dɔɹz. ði oʊnli wɔɹmθ keɪm fɹəm ðə slipɪŋ ænəməlz. ðə tu mɛn ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ saɪlənt ʃædoʊz, bʌt ɡɔɪn kəd fil əm wɑtʃɪŋ ɹeɪjɹ ən ɪm slɪp aʊɾ ɪndə ði aɪsi naɪt. ðeɪ wəd noʊ əbaʊt ðə mɛsənʒɝ, ən bi wʌndɝɪŋ.

"Let's find our what news she brought," he said quietly, motioning Rajar down the ladder ahead of him, Twenty horses and their stacked saddles crowded nearly every inch of the dark barn nor taken by Mistress Millin's two dozen or so milk cows in their stalls, so he and Rajar had to thread their way to the wide doors. The only warmth came from the sleeping animals. The two men guarding the horses were silent shadows, but Gawyn could feel them watching Rajar and him slip out into the icy night. They would know about the messenger, and be wondering.

ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ, ən ðə weɪnɪŋ mun stɪl ɡeɪv ə fɛɹ laɪt. ðə vɪlədʒ ə dɔɹiən ʃoʊn wɪð snoʊ. hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ kloʊks kloʊz, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tʃɹʌdʒ ni-dip θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ ɪn saɪləns, əlɔŋ wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ðə ɹoʊd tə tɑɹ vəlɑn fɹəm ə sɪɾi ðət hæd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪstəd fəɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz.

The sky was clear, and the waning moon still gave a fair light. The village of Dorian shone with snow. Holding their cloaks close, the pair of them trudged knee-deep through the village in silence, along what had once been the road to Tar Valon from a city that had not existed for hundreds of years.

naʊədeɪz, noʊbɑdi tʃɹævəld ɪn ðɪs dɝɛkʃən fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪksɛp tə kʌm tə dɔɹiən, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə kʌm ɪn wɪntɝ. baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən, ðə vɪlədʒ səplaɪd tʃizɪz tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən tə noʊ wʌn ɛls. ɪt wɑz ə taɪni pleɪs, dʒʌs fɪftin sleɪt-ɹuft, ɡɹeɪ stoʊn haʊsəz wɪð dʒɹɪfs ə snoʊ paɪld ʌp əz haɪ əz ðə bɑɾəmz ə ðə fɝst-flɔɹ wɪndoʊz. ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns bɪhaɪn itʃ haʊs stʊɾ ɪts kaʊ bɑɹn eɪl kɹaʊɾəd wɪð mɛn ən hɔɹsəz naʊ, əz wɛl əz kaʊz. moʊst ə tɑɹ vəlɑn maɪt wɛl əv fɝɡɑɾən dɔɹiən ɪɡzɪstəd. hu θɔɾ əbaʊt wɛɹ tʃiz keɪm fɹʌm? ɪt hæd simd ə vɛɹi ɡʊd pleɪs fəɹ kipɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪt. əntɪl naʊ. ɔl ðə haʊsəz bʌt wʌn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ wɝ dɑɹk. laɪt lik θɹu ðə ʃʌɾɝz ɑn sɛvɹəl wɪndoʊz ə mæstɝ bɝloʊz dwɛlɪŋ, əpstɛɹz ən daʊn. ɡɑɹɔn bɝloʊ hæd ðə mɪsfɔɹtʃən tə oʊn ðə lɑɹdʒəs haʊs ɪn dɔɹiən, ɪn ədɪʃən tə biɪŋ meɪɝ. ɛni vɪlɪdʒɝ u hæd ʃɪftəd slipɪŋ ɝeɪnʒmənts tə faɪn ə bɛd fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌs bi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ɪt baɪ naʊ; ən mæstɝ bɝloʊ hæd hæd tu ɹumz ɔlɹɛɾi ɛmpti.

Nowadays, nobody traveled in this direction from Tar Valon except to come to Dorian, and there was no reason to come in winter. By tradition, the village supplied cheeses to the White Tower and to no one else. It was a tiny place, just fifteen slate-roofed, gray stone houses with drifts of snow piled up as high as the bottoms of the first-floor windows. A little distance behind each house stood its cow barn ail crowded with men and horses now, as well as cows. Most of Tar Valon might well have forgotten Dorian existed. Who thought about where cheese came from? It had seemed a very good place for keeping out of sight. Until now. All the houses but one in the village were dark. Light leaked through the shutters on several windows of Master Burlow's dwelling, upstairs and down. Garon Burlow had the misfortune to own the largest house in Dorian, in addition to being Mayor. Any villager who had shifted sleeping arrangements to find a bed for an Aes Sedai must be regretting it by now; and Master Burlow had had two rooms already empty.

stæmpɪŋ ðə snoʊ fɹəm ɪz buts ɑn ðə stoʊn stɛp, ɡɔɪn ɹæpt ɑn ðə meɪɝz staʊt dɔɹ wɪð ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst. noʊ wʌn ænsɝd, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən i lɪftəd ðə lætʃ ən lɛd ɹeɪjɹ ɪn.

Stamping the snow from his boots on the stone step, Gawyn rapped on the Mayor's stout door with a gauntleted fist. No one answered, and after a moment he lifted the latch and led Rajar in.

ðə bim-silɪŋɡd fɹʌn ɹum wɑz fɛɹli lɑɹdʒ fəɹ ə fɑɹmhaʊs, ən dɑməneɪɾəd baɪ sɛvɹəl kɔl oʊpən-fɹʌn kæbənəts, fʊl ə pjuɾɝ ən ɡleɪz kɹɑkɝi ən ə lɔŋ, pɑlɪʃt teɪbəl laɪnd wɪð haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹz. ɔl ə ði ɔɪl læmps hæd bɪn lɪt, ən ɪkstʃɹævəɡəns ɪn wɪntɝ, wən ə fju tæloʊ kændəlz wəd du, bʌt ðə fleɪmz ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs hæd meɪd lɪɾəl ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn ðə splɪt lɔɡz, jɛt, əɹ ɑn ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ ə ðə ɹum. ivən soʊ, ðə tu sɪstɝz u hæd ɹumz əbʌv wɝ bɛɹfʊɾ ɑn ðə ɹʌɡələs wʊɾən flɔɹ, wɪð fɝ-laɪn kloʊks hʌŋ heɪstəli oʊvɝ ðɛɹ lɪnən naɪtdʒɹɛsəz. keɪɾɝin ɔlɹuɾɪn ən tɑɹnə fiɹ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ə smɔl wʊmən ɪn ə dɑɹk jɛloʊ-slæʃt ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ən kloʊk ðət wɝ snoʊ dæmp tə hɝ hɪps. ʃi stʊɾ əz nɪɹ ðə waɪd hɑɹθ əz ʃi wʊd, taɪɹədli wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz ən ʃɪvɝɪŋ. əfʊɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv meɪd ðə tʃɹɪp fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪn lɛs ðən tu əɹ θɹi deɪz, ən ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl ðə koʊld ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ʃi hæd tə bi ðə sɪstɝ ɹeɪjɹ hæd spoʊkən ʌv, jɛt kəmpɛɹd tə ði ʌðɝz, ði eɪɡləsnəs wɑz hɑɹdli noʊɾəsəbəl ɪn hɝ. kəmpɛɹd tə ði ʌðɝ tu, ʃi wɑz hɑɹdli noʊɾəsəbəl əɾ ɔl.

The beam-ceilinged front room was fairly large for a farmhouse, and dominated by several call open-front cabinets, full of pewter and glazed crockery and a long, polished table lined with high-back chairs. All of the oil lamps had been lit, an extravagance in winter, when a few tallow candles would do, but the flames in the fireplace had made little impression on the split logs, yet, or on the temperature of the room. Even so, the two sisters who had rooms above were barefoot on the rugless wooden floor, with fur-lined cloaks hung hastily over their linen nightdresses. Katerine Alruddin and Tarna Feir were watching a small woman in a dark yellow-slashed riding dress and cloak that were snow damp to her hips. She stood as near the wide hearth as she would, tiredly warming her hands and shivering. Afoot in the snow, she could not have made the trip from Tar Valon in less than two or three days, and even Aes Sedai felt the cold eventually. She had to be the sister Rajar had spoken of, yet compared to the others, the agelessness was hardly noticeable in her. Compared to the other two, she was hardly noticeable at all.

ði æbsəns ə ðə meɪɝ ən ɪz waɪf pʊɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə nɑɾ ɪn ɡɔɪnz mɪɾəl, ðoʊ hi hæd hæf ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt. ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ meɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɔfɝɪŋ hɑt dʒɹɪŋks ən fud, noʊ mæɾɝ ði aʊɝ, ənlɛs ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛn bæk tə ðɛɹ bɛdz tə ɡɪv keɪɾɝin ən tɑɹnə pɹaɪvəsi wɪð ðə mɛsənʒɝ. wɪtʃ laɪkli mɛn i wɑz ə ful tə wɑnə noʊ ðə mɛsədʒ. bʌɾ i hæd noʊn ðət bɪfɔɹ i lɛf ðə bɑɹn.

The absence of the Mayor and his wife put an extra knot in Gawyn's middle, though he had half expected it. They would have been there making over the Aes Sedai, offering hot drinks and food, no matter the hour, unless they had been sent back to their beds to give Katerine and Tarna privacy with the messenger. Which likely meant he was a fool to want to know the message. But he had known that before he left the barn.

"... boʊtmən sɛɾ i wəd steɪ wɛɹ wi lændəɾ əntɪl ðə sidʒ lɪftəd," ðə smɔl wʊmən wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪn wɪɹi toʊnz əz ɡɔɪn ɛntɝd., "bʌɾ i wɑz soʊ fɹaɪɾənd, hi kəd bi liɡz daʊnɹɪvɝ baɪ naʊ." əz ðə koʊl fɹəm ðə dɔɹweɪ ɹitʃt hɝ, ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊnd., ən səm ə ðə fətiɡ dʒɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ skwɛɹ feɪs. "ɡɔɪn tʃɹəkənd" ʃi sɛd. "aɪ hæv ɔɹɾɝz fəɹ jə fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, lɔɹd ɡɔɪn."

"... boatman said he would stay where we landed until the siege lifted," the small woman was saying in weary tones as Gawyn entered., "but he was so frightened, he could be leagues downriver by now." As the cold from the doorway reached her, she looked around., and some of the fatigue drained from her square face. "Gawyn Trakand" she said. "I have orders for you from the Amyrlin Seat, Lord Gawyn."

"ɔɹɾɝz?" ɡɔɪn sɛd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɔft ɪz ɡɔnləts ən tʌkɪŋ əm bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛl tə ɡeɪn taɪm.

"Orders?" Gawyn said, drawing oft his gauntlets and tucking them behind his belt to gain time.

blʌn tʃɹuθ maɪt bi ɪn ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ wʌns, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd, "waɪ wəɾ ɪleɪɾə sɛn mi ɔɹɾɝz? waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ oʊbeɪ ɪf ʃi dɪd? ʃi dɪsoʊn mi, ən ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz." ɹeɪjɹ hæd teɪkən ə ɹɪspɛkfəl stæns fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz, hænz foʊldəd bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, ən i ɡeɪv ɡɔɪn ə kwɪk saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns. hi wəd nɑt spik aʊɾ ə tɝn, wʌtɛvɝ ɡɔɪn sɛd, bʌt ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ ɡɔɪnz bɪlif. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd wʌt ðeɪ dɪd, ən noʊ mæn kəd noʊ waɪ əntɪl ə sɪstɝ toʊl hɪm. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz hæd kæs ðɛɹ lɑts wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ hoʊl-hɑɹɾɪdli, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ feɪt.

Blunt truth might be in order for once, he decided, "Why would Elaida send me orders? Why should I obey if she did? She disowned me, and the Younglings." Rajar had taken a respectful stance for the sisters, hands folded behind his back, and he gave Gawyn a quick sidelong glance. He would not speak out of turn, whatever Gawyn said, but the Younglings did not share Gawyn's belief. Aes Sedai did what they did, and no man could know why until a sister told him. The Younglings had cast their lots with the White Tower whole-heartedly, embracing fate.

"ðæt kən weɪt, nɛɹənwɪn," keɪɾɝin snæpt, dʒɝkɪŋ əɹ kloʊk taɪɾɝ. hɝ blæk hɛɹ spɪld ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz hæf ɪn tæŋɡəlz, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd teɪkən ə fju heɪsti swaɪps wɪð ə koʊm ən ɡɪvən ʌp. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪntɛnsəɾi əbaʊɾ əɹ ðət ɹimaɪndəd ɡɔɪn ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ lɪŋks. əɹ meɪbi wʌn wɛɹi ʌv tʃɹæps. ʃi spɛɹd hæf ə ɡlæns fəɹ ɪm ən ɹeɪjɹ; noʊ mɔɹ, "aɪ hæv pɹɛsɪŋ bɪznəs ɪn ðə taʊɝ. tɛl mi haʊ tə faɪn ðɪs neɪmləs fɪʃɪŋ vɪlədʒ. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt jəɹ boʊtmən ɪz stɪl ðɛɹ, əl faɪn sʌmwʌn tə teɪk mi əkɹɔs."

"That can wait, Narenwin," Katerine snapped, jerking her cloak tighter. Her black hair spilled around her shoulders half in tangles, as though she had taken a few hasty swipes with a comb and given up. There was an intensity about her that reminded Gawyn of a hunting lynx. Or maybe one wary of traps. She spared half a glance for him and Rajar; no more, "I have pressing business in the Tower. Tell me how to find this nameless fishing village. Whether or not your boatman is still there, I'll find someone to take me across."

"æn mi," tɑɹnə pʊɾ ɪn, hɝ stʃɹɔŋ dʒɔ stʌbɝn ən əɹ blu aɪz ʃɑɹp əz spɪɹz. ɪn kɑntʃɹæs tə keɪɾɝin, tɑɹnəz lɔŋ, peɪl jɛloʊ hɛɹ wɑz əz niɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd hæɾ ə meɪɾ ətɛndɪŋ əɹ bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ daʊnstɛɹz. ʃi wɑz ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz foʊkəst, ðoʊ, dʒʌs mɔɹ kəntʃɹoʊld, "aɪ ɔlsoʊ hæv ɝdʒən ɹizən tə ɹitʃ ðə taʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni fɝðɝ dɪleɪ." ʃi ɡeɪv ɡɔɪn ə nɑɾ ən ɹeɪjɹ ə lɛsɝ, kul əz ðə mɑɹbəl ʃi sim kɑɹv fɹʌm. jɛt, mɔɹ fɹɛnli ðən ðə feɪs ʃi ʃoʊd keɪɾɝin əɹ ɡɑɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə stɪfnəs bɪtwin ðə tu wɪmən, ðoʊ ðeɪ ʃɛɹd ðə seɪm ədʒɑ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk wʌn ənʌðɝ, pɝhæps ivən dɪslaɪkt itʃ ʌðɝ. wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bi ʃʊɹ.

"And me," Tarna put in, her strong jaw stubborn and her blue eyes sharp as spears. In contrast to Katerine, Tarna's long, pale yellow hair was as neat as if she had had a maid attending her before coming downstairs. She was every bit as focused, though, just more controlled, "I also have urgent reason to reach the Tower without any further delay." She gave Gawyn a nod and Rajar a lesser, cool as the marble she seemed carved from. Yet, more friendly than the face she showed Katerine or got in return. There was always a stiffness between the two women, though they shared the same Ajah. They did not like one another, perhaps even disliked each other. With Aes Sedai, it was hard to be sure.

ɡɔɪn wəd nɑt bi sɑɹi tə si iðɝ liv. tɑɹnə hæd ɹɪɾən ɪndə dɔɹiən bɛɹli ə deɪ æftɝ ðə mɪstɪɹiəs ɑɹmi ɝaɪvd, ən haʊɛvɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪtɝmən ðiz θɪŋz, ʃi ɪmiɾiətli dɪspleɪs lusoʊniə koʊl fɹəm əɹ ɹum əpstɛɹz ən koʊvɑɹlə bɪldin fɹəm kəmæn ə ði ɪlɛvən ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə ɡɹin fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi tʊk tʃɑɹdʒ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ, kwɛstʃənɪŋ ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz əbaʊt ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, ivən ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz kloʊsli ɛvɹi deɪ əz ðoʊ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ pɑsəbəl wɔɹɾɝz. hævɪŋ ə ɹɛd stʌɾi ðɛm ðət weɪ meɪd ðə mɛn stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. wɝs, tɑɹnə spɛn lɔŋ aʊɝz aʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ, noʊ mæɾɝ ðə wɛðɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn səm loʊkəl u kəd ʃoʊ hɝ ə weɪ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi pæs ðə bɪsiɡɝz. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ʃi wəd lɛd ðɛɹ skaʊts bæk tə dɔɹiən. keɪɾɝin hæd kʌm oʊnli jɛstɝdeɪ, ɪn ə fjʊɹi ət hævɪŋ əɹ pæθ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn blɑkt, ən stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ tʊk kəmæn fɹəm tɑɹnə ən əɹ ɹum fɹəm koʊvɑɹlə. nɑt ðət ʃi juzd əɹ əθɔɹəɾi ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ. ʃi əvɔɪɾəd ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə tɛl ɛniwʌn waɪ ʃi hæd dɪsəpɪɹɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz əɹ wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn. bʌt ʃi, tu, hæɾ ɪnspɛktɪd ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz. wɪð ən ɛɹ ʌv ə wʊmən ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ən æks ʃi hæɾ ə maɪn tə juz, ən nɑɾ ə kɛɹ haʊ mʌtʃ blʌd wɑz ʃɛd.

Gawyn would not be sorry to see either leave. Tarna had ridden into Dorian barely a day after the mysterious army arrived, and however Aes Sedai determined these things, she immediately displaced Lusonia Cole from her room upstairs and Covarla Bildene from command of the eleven other sisters already in the village. She might have been a Green from the way she took charge of everything, questioning the other sisters about the situation, even inspecting the Younglings closely every day as though searching for possible Warders. Having a Red study them that way made the men start looking over their shoulders. Worse, Tarna spent long hours out riding, no matter the weather, trying to find some local who could show her a way into the city past the besiegers. Sooner or later, she would lead their scouts back to Dorian. Katerine had come only yesterday, in a fury at having her path to Tar Valon blocked, and straightaway took command from Tarna and her room from Covarla. Not that she used her authority in the same way. She avoided the other sisters, refusing to tell anyone why she had disappeared at Dumai's Wells or where she had been. But she, too, had inspected the Younglings. With an air of a woman examining an axe she had a mind to use, and not a care how much blood was shed.

hi wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə bʊli hɪm ɪndə kʌt-tɪŋ ə weɪ tə ðə bɹɪdʒəz ɪndə ðə sɪɾi fəɹ hɝ. hi wəd bi mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə si ðɛm ɡoʊ, ɪn fækt. bʌt ðɛn, wən ðeɪ lɛft, hi wəɾ əv tə dil wɪð nɛɹənwɪn. ən wɪð ɪleɪɾəz ɔɹɾɝz.

He would not have been surprised if she had tried to bully him into cut-ting a way to the bridges into the city for her. He would be more than happy to see them go, in fact. But then, when they left, he would have to deal with Narenwin. And with Elaida's orders.

"ɪts hɑɹdli ə vɪlədʒ, keɪɾɝin," ðə ʃɪvɝɪŋ sɪstɝ sɛd, "dʒʌs θɹi əɹ fɔɹ skwɑləd lɪɾəl fɪʃɝmænz haʊzɪz ə hɪl deɪ daʊnɹɪvɝ baɪ lænd. mɔɹ ðən ðət fɹəm hɪɹ." plʌkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dæmp skɝts, ʃi hɛld əm nɪɹɝ ðə faɪɝ. "wi meɪ bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ə weɪ tə sɛn mɛsədʒəz ɪndə ðə sɪɾi bʌt jə tu ɑɹ niɾəd hɪɹ. ɔl ðət stɑpt ɪleɪɾə sɛndɪŋ fɪfti sɪstɝz, əɹ mɔɹ, ɹæðɝ ðən dʒʌs mi, wɑz ðə dɪfəkəlti ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ivən wʌn taɪni boʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ ənsin, ivən ɪn dɑɹknəs. aɪ mʌst seɪ, aɪ wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə lɝn ðəɹ wɝ ɛni sɪstɝz ðɪs kloʊs tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u ɪz aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi mʌst-"

"It's hardly a village, Katerine," the shivering sister said, "just three or four squalid little fisherman's houses a hill day downriver by land. More than that from here." Plucking at her damp skirts, she held them nearer the fire. "We may be able to find a way to send messages into the city but you two are needed here. All that stopped Elaida sending fifty sisters, or more, rather than just me, was the difficulty of getting even one tiny boat across the river unseen, even in darkness. I must say, I was surprised to learn there were any sisters this close to Tar Valon. Under the circumstances, every sister who is outside the city must-"

tɑɹnə kʌɾ əɹ ɔf fɝmli wɪð ə ɹeɪz hænd. "ɪleɪɾə kænɑɾ ivən noʊ aɪm hɪɹ." keɪɾɝin kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ ən fɹaʊnd, hɝ tʃɪn lɪftɪŋ, bʌt ʃi lɛt ði ʌðɝ ɹɛd kəntɪnju. "wʌt wɝ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz tə jə ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz ɪn dɔɹiən, nɛɹənwɪn?" ɹeɪjɹ tʊk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz bʊɹz. hi hæd feɪs bæɾəl wɪθaʊt flɪntʃɪŋ, jɛɾ oʊnli ə ful wɑntəd tə bi ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ.

Tarna cut her off firmly with a raised hand. "Elaida cannot even know I am here." Katerine closed her mouth and frowned, her chin lifting, but she let the other Red continue. "What were her orders to you regarding the sisters in Dorian, Narenwin?" Rajar took to studying the floorboards in front of his boors. He had faced battle without flinching, yet only a fool wanted to be around Aes Sedai who were arguing.

ðə ʃɔɹt wʊmən fʌst wɪð əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ. "aɪ wɑz ɔɹɾɝd tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə sɪstɝz aɪ faʊn hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd stʌfəli, "æn də wʌɾ aɪ kʊd." æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi saɪd, ən əmɛndəd hɝsɛlf ɹɪlʌktənli. "ðə sɪstɝz aɪ faʊn hɪɹ ʌndɝ koʊvɑɹlə. bʌt, ʃʊɹli-" ðɪs taɪm, keɪɾɝin bɹoʊk ɪn "aɪ wɑz nɛvɝ ʌndɝ koʊvɑɹlə, nɛɹənwɪn, soʊ ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz kænɑɾ əplaɪ tə mi. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əl sɛɾ aʊt tə faɪn ðiz θɹi əɹ fɔɹ fɪʃɝmænz hʌts."

The short woman fussed with her divided skirts a moment longer. "I was ordered to take charge of the sisters I found here," she said stuffily, "and do what I could." After a moment, she sighed, and amended herself reluctantly. "The sisters I found here under Covarla. But, surely-" This time, Katerine broke in "I was never under Covarla, Narenwin, so those orders cannot apply to me. In the morning, I will set out to find these three or four fisherman's huts."

"bʌt-"

"But-"

"ɪnʌf, nɛɹənwɪn," keɪɾɝin sɛɾ ɪn ən aɪsi vɔɪs. "ju kən meɪk jəɹ ɝeɪnʒmənts wɪð koʊvɑɹlə." ðə blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən ɡeɪv əɹ ədʒɑ sɪstɝ ə ɡlæns fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. "aɪ səpoʊz jə meɪ əkʌmpəni mi, tɑɹnə. ə fɪʃɪŋ boʊt ʃəɾ əv ɹum fəɹ tu." tɑɹnə bɛn əɹ hɛd ðə slaɪɾəst fɹækʃən, pɑsəbli ɪn θæŋks.

"Enough, Narenwin," Katerine said in an icy voice. "You can make your arrangements with Covarla." The black-haired woman gave her Ajah sister a glance from the corner of her eye. "I suppose you may accompany me, Tarna. A fishing boat should have room for two." Tarna bent her head the slightest fraction, possibly in thanks.

ðɛɹ bɪznəs kənkluɾəd, ðə pɛɹ ə ɹɛdz ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ kloʊks ɝaʊn əm ən ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ dipɝ ɪndə ðə haʊs. nɛɹənwɪn ʃɑɾ ə vɛks lʊk ət ðɛɹ bæks ən tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə ɡɔɪn, hɝ feɪs sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɛmbləns ʌv ə kɑm mæsk.

Their business concluded, the pair of Reds gathered their cloaks around them and glided toward the door deeper into the house. Narenwin shot a vexed look at their backs and turned her attention to Gawyn, her face settling into the semblance of a calm mask.

"hæv jə ɛni wɝɾ ə maɪ sɪstɝ?" hi æsk bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "du jə noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz?" ðə wʊmən ɹɪli wɑz taɪɝd. ʃi blɪŋkt, ən i kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si hɝ fɔɹmɪŋ ən ænsɝ ðət wəd tɛl ɪm nʌθɪŋ.

"Have you any word of my sister?" he asked before she could open her mouth. "Do you know where she is?" The woman really was tired. She blinked, and he could almost see her forming an answer that would tell him nothing.

stɑpɪŋ hæfweɪ tə ðə dɔɹ, tɑɹnə sɛd, "ɪleɪn wɑz wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz wən aɪ sɔ hɝ læst." ɛvɹi hɛd dʒɝk təwɔɹd hɝ. "bʌt jəɹ sɪstɝ ɪz seɪf fɹəm ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən," ʃi wɛn ɑn kɑmli "soʊ pʊt ðəɾ əɹ ə jəɹ maɪnd. æksɛptɪd kæn tʃuz wɪtʃ sɪstɝz tə oʊbeɪ. aɪ ɡɪv jə maɪ wɝd; ʌndɝ ðə lɔ, ʃi kən sʌfɝ noʊ læstɪŋ hɑɹm ʌv ɪt.' ʃi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə keɪɾɝinz fɹoʊzən stɛɹ, əɹ nɛɹənwɪnz pɑpɪŋ aɪz.

Stopping halfway to the door, Tarna said, "Elayne was with the rebels when I saw her last." Every head jerked toward her. "But your sister is safe from retribution," she went on calmly "so put that our of your mind. Accepted can't choose which sisters to obey. I give you my word; under the law, she can suffer no lasting harm of it.' She seemed unaware of Katerine's frozen stare, or Narenwin's popping eyes.

"ju cʊɾə toʊl mi bɪfɔɹ ðɪs," ɡɔɪn sɛd ɹʌfli. noʊ wʌn spoʊk ɹʌfli tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑt mɔɹ ðən wʌns bʌɾ i wɑz pæs kɛɹɪŋ. wɝ ði ʌðɝ tu sɝpɹaɪz ðət tɑɹnə nu ði ænsɝ, əɹ sɝpɹaɪz ðət ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ɪt? "wʌt dʒju min baɪ noʊ læstɪŋ hɑɹm?" ðə peɪl-hɛɹd sɪstɝ bɑɹkt ə læf. "aɪ kən hɑɹdli pɹɑməs ʃi woʊn sʌfɝ ə fju wɛls ɪf ʃi pʊts əɹ fit tu fɑɹ ɹɔŋ. ɪleɪn ɪz wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. jɛt ðət pɹətɛks əɹ fɹəm ɡɹeɪɾɝ hɑɹm ɪf ʃiz lɛɾ əstʃɹeɪ baɪ ə sɪstɝ. ən jə nɛvɝ æskt. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi dʌznt nid ɹɛskjuɪŋ, ivən ɪf jə kəd mænədʒ ɪt. ʃiz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. naʊ jə noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ kən tɛl jə ʌv hɝ, ən aɪm gɑnə faɪn ə fju aʊɝz mɔɹ slip bɪfɔɹ deɪlaɪt. əl liv jə tə nɛɹənwɪn." keɪɾɝin wɑtʃt əɹ ɡoʊ wɪθaʊɾ ɔltɝɪŋ əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən baɪ ən aɪlæʃ, ə wʊmən ʌv aɪs wɪð ði aɪz ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ kæt, bʌt ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf stʃɹoʊd fɹəm ðə ɹum soʊ kwɪkli ðəɾ əɹ kloʊk flɛɹd bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"You could have told me before this," Gawyn said roughly. No one spoke roughly to Aes Sedai, not more then once but he was past caring. Were the other two surprised that Tarna knew the answer, or surprised that she had given it? "What do you mean by no lasting harm?" The pale-haired sister barked a laugh. "I can hardly promise she won't suffer a few welts if she puts her feet too far wrong. Elayne is one of the Accepted, not Aes Sedai. Yet that protects her from greater harm if she is led astray by a sister. And you never asked. Besides, she doesn't need rescuing, even if you could manage it. She is with Aes Sedai. Now you know as much as I can tell you of her, and I am going to find a few hours more sleep before daylight. I will leave you to Narenwin." Katerine watched her go without altering her expression by an eyelash, a woman of ice with the eyes of a hunting cat, but then she herself strode from the room so quickly that her cloak flared behind her.

"tɑɹnə ɪz kɝɛkt," nɛɹənwɪn sɛd wʌns ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn keɪɾɝin. ðə smɔl wʊmən maɪt nɑt meɪk ə ɡʊd ʃoʊ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi ən mɪstɝi əlɔŋsaɪd ði ʌðɝ tu, bʌɾ əloʊn ʃi mænədʒ vɛɹi wɛl. "ɪleɪn ɪz sil tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. soʊ ɑɹ ju, fəɹ ɔl jəɹ tɔk ə dɪsaʊnɪŋ.

"Tarna is correct," Narenwin said once the door closed behind Katerine. The small woman might not make a good show of Aes Sedai serenity and mystery alongside the other two, but alone she managed very well. "Elayne is sealed to the White Tower. So are you, for all your talk of disowning.

ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ silz jə tə ðə taʊɝ."

The history of Andor seals you to the Tower."

"ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz ɑɹ ɔl sil tə ðə taʊɝ baɪ əɹ oʊn tʃɔɪs, nɛɹənwɪn sədaɪ," ɹeɪjɹ sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə lɛɡ fɔɹməli. nɛɹənwɪnz ɡeɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɡɔɪn. hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də nɔɹ tə skɹʌb əɾ əm wɪð ðə hilz əɹ ɪz hænz. ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wɝ sil tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ fɔɹdʒɝ ðət ðeɪ hæd fɔt, ɑn ðə vɛɹi ɡɹaʊnz ə ðə taʊɝ, tə stɑp ðə ɹɛskju ʌv ə dɪpoʊzd æmɪɝlɪn. fəɹ ɡʊɾ əɹ ɪl, ðə teɪl wəd fɑloʊ ðɛm tə ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪvz. hi wɑz mɑɹk baɪ ðæt, əz wɛl, ən baɪ hɪz oʊn sikɹəts. æftɝ ɔl ðət blʌdʃɛd, hi wɑz ðə mæn u hæd lɝ sɪuən sɑntʃ wɔk fɹi. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, ðoʊ, ɪleɪn baʊn ɪm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən soʊ dɪɾ ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ən i dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ taɪd ðə taɪɾɝ nɑt, ðə lʌv ə hɪz sɪstɝ əɹ ðə lʌv ə hɪz hɑɹt. tə əbændən wʌn wɑz tə əbændən ɔl θɹi, ən waɪl i bɹiðd, hi kəd nɑɾ əbændən ɪleɪn əɹ ɛɡwin.

"The Younglings are all sealed to the Tower by our own choice, Narenwin Sedai," Rajar said, making a leg formally. Narenwin's gaze remained on Gawyn. He closed his eyes, and it was all he could do nor to scrub at them with the heels or his hands. The Younglings were sealed to the White Tower. No one would ever forger that they had fought, on the very grounds of the Tower, to stop the rescue of a deposed Amyrlin. For good or ill, the tale would follow them to their graves. He was marked by that, as well, and by his own secrets. After all that bloodshed, he was the man who had ler Siuan Sanche walk free. More importantly, though, Elayne bound him to the White Tower, and so did Egwene al'Vere, and he did not know which tied the tighter knot, the love of his sister or the love of his heart. To abandon one was to abandon all three, and while he breathed, he could not abandon Elayne or Egwene.

"ju hæv maɪ wɝd ðəɾ əl də ɔl aɪ kæn," hi sɛd wɛɹəli.' wʌt dʌz ɪleɪɾə wɑn ə mi?" ðə skaɪ əbʌv keɪɛmlɪn wɑz klɪɹ, ðə sʌn ə peɪl ɡoʊldən bɔl nɪɹ ɪts nundeɪ pik. ɪt ʃɛɾ ə bɹɪljən laɪɾ ɑn ðə blæŋkəɾ ʌv waɪt kʌvɝɪŋ ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹisaɪd, bʌt ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ. stɪl, ðə wɛðɝ wɑz wɔɹmɝ ðən dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd bæk hoʊm ɪn sɑldɑiə, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɹəɡɹɛt ðə mɑɹɾən-fɝ laɪnɪŋ ɪz nu kloʊk. koʊld ɪnʌf ɪn ɛni keɪs fəɹ ɪz bɹɛθ tə hæv fɹɔstəɾ ɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz wɪð mɔɹ waɪt ðən ðə jɪɹz hæd pʊɾ ɪn ðɛm. stændɪŋ ɪn æŋkəl-dip snoʊ əmʌŋ ðə lifləs tʃɹiz ɑn ə ɹaɪz pɝhæps ə liɡ nɔɹθ ə keɪɛmlɪn, hi hɛld ə lɔŋ, ɡoʊld-maʊntəd lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɪz aɪ, stʌɾiɪŋ ði æktɪvəɾi ɑn loʊɝ ɡɹaʊn əbaʊɾ ə maɪl saʊθ ə hɪm. kwɪk noʊzd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪmpeɪʃənli fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹd ðə beɪ. kwɪk dɪslaɪk stændɪŋ stɪl, bʌt səmtaɪmz jə hæd tə, wʌtɛvɝ jə wɑntəd.

"You have my word that I will do all I can," he said wearily.' What does Elaida want of me?" The sky above Caemlyn was clear, the sun a pale golden ball near its noonday peak. It shed a brilliant light on the blanket of white covering the surrounding countryside, but gave no warmth. Still, the weather was warmer than Davram Bashere would have expected back home in Saldaea, though he did not regret the marten-fur lining his new cloak. Cold enough in any case for his breath to have frosted his thick mustaches with more white than the years had put in them. Standing in ankle-deep snow among the leafless trees on a rise perhaps a league north of Caemlyn, he held a long, gold-mounted looking glass to his eye, studying the activity on lower ground about a mile south of him. Quick nosed his shoulder impatiently from behind, but he ignored the bay. Quick disliked standing still, but sometimes you had to, whatever you wanted.

ə spɹɔlɪŋ kæmp wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp daʊn ðəɹ əmʌŋ ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz, əstʃɹaɪd ðə ɹoʊd tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, soʊlʒɝz ənloʊɾɪŋ səplaɪ wæɡənz, dɪɡɪŋ lætʃɹinz, ɪɹɛktɪŋ tɛns ən bɪldɪŋ lin-tɑz ə bɹʌʃ ən tʃɹi-lɪmz skæɾɝd ɪn klʌmps ə vɛɹiɪŋ saɪz, itʃ lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi kipɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn mɛn kloʊs.

A sprawling camp was going up down there among the scattered trees, astride the road to Tar Valon, soldiers unloading supply wagons, digging latrines, erecting tents and building lean-tos of brush and tree-limbs scattered in clumps of varying size, each lord and lady keeping their own men close.

ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə bi ɪn pleɪs fəɹ səm taɪm. fɹəm ðə hɔɹs-laɪnz ən ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɪkstɛn ə ðə kæmp, hi ɛstəmeɪɾəd kloʊs tə faɪv θaʊzən mɛn, ɡɪv əɹ teɪk ə fju hʌnʒɹəd. faɪɾɪŋ mɛn: flɛtʃɝz, fɛɹiɝz, ɑɹmɔɹɝz, lɔnʒɹəsəz, wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ʌðɝ kæmp fɑloʊɝz əz ɡʊɾ əz dʌbəl ðæt, ðoʊ əz juʒəwəl ðeɪ wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn kæmp ɑn ðə fɹɪnʒɪz. moʊst ə ðə kæmp fɑloʊɝz spɛn mɔɹ taɪm stɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹaɪz wɛɹ bæʃɪɹ stʊd ðən ðeɪ dɪd wɝkɪŋ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə soʊlʒɝ pɔzd ɪn ɪz leɪbɝz tə pɪɹ təwɔɹd ðə haɪɝ ɡɹaʊnd, tu, bʌt bænɝmɪn ən skwədmən kwɪkli dʒɹoʊv əm bæk tə ðɛɹ wɝk. ðə noʊbəlz ən ɔfəsɝz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ kæmp nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns nɔɹθ, ðət bæʃɪɹ sɔ. ə foʊld ə læn hɪɾ əm fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ hi kəd si ðə sɪlvɝ-stʃɹikt ɡɹeɪ wɔlz fɹəm ɪz ɹaɪz. ðə sɪɾi nu ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs; ðeɪ hæɾ ənaʊns ðɛmsɛlvz ðət mɔɹnɪŋ wɪð tʃɹʌmpəts ən bænɝz ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə wɔlz. wɛl aʊɾ ə baʊʃɑt, ðoʊ-leɪɪŋ sidʒ tə ə sɪɾi wɪð haɪ, stʃɹɔŋ wɔlz ðət stʃɹɛtʃt mɔɹ ðən sɪks liɡz ɪn sɝkʌmfɹəns wɑz noʊ izi mæɾɝ, ən kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ɪn ðɪs ɪnstəns baɪ loʊ keɪɛmlɪn, ðə wɔɹən ə bɹɪk ən stoʊn haʊsəz ən ʃɑps, wɪndoʊləs wɛɹhaʊzɪz ən lɔŋ mɑɹkəts, ðət leɪ aʊtsaɪd keɪɛmlɪnz wɔlz. sɛvən mɔɹ laɪk kæmps wɝ biɪŋ meɪd, ðoʊ, speɪst ɝaʊn ðə sɪɾi wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd kʌvɝ ɛvɹi ɹoʊd, ɛvɹi ɡeɪt ðət wəɾ əlaʊ ə saɪzəbəl, sɔɹɾi. ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd pətʃɹoʊlz aʊt, ən laɪkli wɑtʃɝz lɝkt ɪn ðə naʊ-dɪzɝɾɪd bɪldɪŋz ə loʊ keɪɛmlɪn. smɔl pɑɹɾiz maɪt ɡɛt pæst ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, meɪbi ə fju pæk ænəməlz baɪ naɪt, bʌt nɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə fid wʌn ə ðə wɝlz ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz. hʌŋɡɝ ən dɪziz ɛndəd mɔɹ sidʒəz ðən sɔɹdz əɹ sidʒ-ɛnʒənz ɛvɝ dɪd. ði oʊnli kwɛstʃən wɑz wɛðɝ ðeɪ bɹɔt daʊn bɪsidʒd əɹ bɪsiɡɝ fɝst.

They expected to be in place for some time. From the horse-lines and the general extent of the camp, he estimated close to five thousand men, give or take a few hundred. Fighting men: fletchers, farriers, armorers, laundresses, wagon drivers and other camp followers as good as doubled that, though as usual they were making their own camp on the fringes. Most of the camp followers spent more time staring toward the rise where Bashere stood than they did working. Here and there a soldier paused in his labors to peer toward the higher ground, too, but bannermen and squadmen quickly drove them back to their work. The nobles and officers riding about the rising camp never so much as glanced north, that Bashere saw. A fold of land hid them from the city, though he could see the silver-streaked gray walls from his rise. The city knew they were there, of course; they had announced themselves that morning with trumpets and banners in sight of the walls. Well out of bowshot, though-Laying siege to a city with high, strong walls that stretched more than six leagues in circumference was no easy matter, and complicated in this instance by Low Caemlyn, the warren of brick and stone houses and shops, windowless warehouses and long markets, that lay outside Caemlyn's walls. Seven more like camps were being made, though, spaced around the city where they could cover every road, every gate that would allow a sizable, sortie. They already had patrols out, and likely watchers lurked in the now-deserted buildings of Low Caemlyn. Small parties might get past into the city, maybe a few pack animals by night, but not near enough to feed one of the world's great cities. Hunger and disease ended more sieges than swords or siege-engines ever did. The only question was whether they brought down besieged or besieger first.

ðə plæn simɪŋli hæɾ ɔl bɪn wɛl θɔt-aʊt baɪ sʌmwʌn, bʌt wʌt kənfjuzd ɪm wɝ ðə bænɝz ɪn ðə kæmp bɪloʊ. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹɔŋ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, kɹæftɪd baɪ ə kɛɹhinɪn neɪm tʌvɪɹ, ə ɡɪft fɹəm ɹænd ælθɹ, ən i kəd meɪk aʊt moʊst ə ðə bænɝz wɛnɛvɝ ə bɹiz stʃɹeɪɾənd ðɛm. hi nu ɪnʌf ʌv ændɔɝən sɪɡəlz tə pɪk aʊt ði oʊk ən æks ə dɔlɪn, ɑɹmɑɡn ən ðə faɪv sɪlvɝ stɑɹz ə dɛɝɪlə ɹænd ən sɛvɹəl mɔɹ bænɝz ə lɛsɝ noʊbəlz u səpɔɹɾəd nɑiən ɑɝɔnz kleɪm tə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn ən ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ʌv ændɝ. jɛt dʒeɪlɪn mɑɹɑnz kɹɔs-lɝtʃt ɹɛd wɔl wɑz daʊn ðɛɹ, ku, ən kɑɹliz əŋkɝɪnz pɛɹd waɪt lɛpɝdz, ən ɛɹeɪn tɔkɛnz ɡoʊldən wɪŋ hænd. baɪ ɔl ɹɪpɔɹts, ðeɪ wɝ oʊθ-swɔɹn tə nɑiənz ɹaɪvəl ɛləniə sɑɝənd. siɪŋ əm wɪð ði ʌðɝz wɑz laɪk siɪŋ wʊlvz ən wʊlfhnz ʃɛɹɪŋ ə mil. wɪð ə kæsk ʌv ɡʊd waɪn oʊpən ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən-tu ʌðɝ bænɝz, ɡoʊld-fɹɪn ən ət lis twaɪs ðə saɪz ʌv ɛni ʌðɝz, wɝ ɑn dɪspleɪ əz wɛl, ðoʊ boʊθ wɝ tu hɛvi fəɹ ði əkeɪʒənəl ɡʌs tə meɪk əm mɔɹ ðən stɝ. ðeɪ ʃoʊn wɪð ðə ɡlɪsən ə θɪk sɪlk. hi hæd sin ðə pɛɹ klɪɹli ɪnʌf ɝliɝ, haʊɛvɝ, wən ðə bænɝ-mɛn ɹoʊd bæk ən fɔɹθ ətɑp ðə ɹaɪz ðət hɪd ðɛɹ kæmp, ðə bænɝz spɹɛɾ aʊɾ əbʌv əm ɪn ðə bɹiz ə ðɛɹ ɡæləp.

The plan seemingly had all been well thought-out by someone, but what confused him were the banners in the camp below. It was a strong looking glass, crafted by a Cairhienin named Tovere, a gift from Rand al'Thor, and he could make out most of the banners whenever a breeze straightened them. He knew enough of Andoran sigils to pick out the Oak and Axe of Dawlin, Armaghn and the five Silver Stars of Daerilla Raned and several more banners of lesser nobles who supported Naean Arawn's claim to the Lion Throne and the Rose Crown of Andor. Yet Jailin Maran's cross-lurched Red Wall was down there, coo, and Carlys Ankerin's paired White Leopards, and Erain Talkend's golden Winged Hand. By all reports, they were oath-sworn to Naean's rival Elenia Sarand. Seeing them with the others was like seeing wolves and wolfhounds sharing a meal. With a cask of good wine opened in the bargain-Two other banners, gold-fringed and at least twice the size of any others, were on display as well, though both were too heavy for the occasional gust to make them more than stir. They shone with the glisten of thick silk. He had seen the pair clearly enough earlier, however, when the banner-men rode back and forth atop the rise that hid their camp, the banners spread out above them in the breeze of their gallop.

wʌn wɑz ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ, waɪɾ ɑn ɹɛd, ðə seɪm əz flu fɹəm ðə tɔl ɹaʊn taʊɝz dɑɾəd əlɔŋ ðə sɪɾi wɔl. ɪn boʊθ keɪsəz ɪt wɑz ə dɛklɝeɪʃən ə sʌmwʌnz ɹaɪt tə ðə θɹoʊn ən kɹaʊn. ðə sɛkən lɑɹdʒ bænɝ bɪloʊ hɪm pɹoʊkleɪm ðə wʊmən θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ kleɪm əɡɛns ðəɾ ʌv ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd. fɔɹ sɪlvɝ munz ɑn ə fild ə twaɪlaɪt blu, ðə saɪn ə haʊs mɑɹn. ɔl ðɪs wɑz ɪn səpɔɹɾ ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn? ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn lʌki ɪf ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt əɹ oʊn haʊs əɹ ðət hæf-wɪɾɪd næsən kɝən ɡeɪv əɹ ə bɛd fəɹ ðə naɪt!

One was the Lion of Andor, white on red, the same as flew from the tall round towers dotted along the city wall. In both cases it was a declaration of someone's right to the throne and crown. The second large banner below him proclaimed the woman throwing her claim against that of Elayne Trakand. Four silver moons on a field of twilight blue, the sign of House Marne. All this was in support of Arymilla Marne? A month ago, she would have been lucky if anyone except her own House or that half-witted Nasin Caeren gave her a bed for the night!

"ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹ ʌs," beɪl ɡɹaʊld. aɪ kəd bɹeɪk əm bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt, ən liv nɑt wʌn əlaɪv tə si ðə sʌn ɹaɪz əɡɛn, jɛt ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹ ʌs."

"They ignore us," Bael growled. I could break them before sunset, and leave not one alive to see the sun rise again, yet they ignore us."

bæʃɪɹ lʊk saɪdweɪz ət ði ilmən. saɪdweɪz ən ʌp. ðə mæn taʊɝɾ əbʌv ɪm baɪ wɛl oʊvɝ ə fʊt. oʊnli beɪlz ɡɹeɪ aɪz ən ə stʃɹɪp ə sʌn-dɑɹk skɪn wɝ vɪzəbəl əbʌv ðə blæk veɪl dʒɹɔn əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. bæʃɪɹ hoʊp ðə mæn wɑz dʒʌst ʃildɪŋ ɪz maʊθ ən noʊz fɹəm ðə koʊld-hi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ɪz ʃɔɹt spɪɹz ən bʊl-haɪd bʌkəlɝ, ən i hæɾ ə keɪs baʊ ɑn ɪz bæk ən ə kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz hɪp, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə veɪl mæɾɝd. ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ði il tə stɑɹt kɪlɪŋ. twɛnti peɪsɪz daʊn sloʊp təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, θɝɾi mɔɹ ilmɛn wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛpənz kæʒəwəli.

Bashere looked sideways at the Aielman. Sideways and up. The man towered above him by well over a foot. Only Bael's gray eyes and a strip of sun-dark skin were visible above the black veil drawn across his face. Bashere hoped the man was just shielding his mouth and nose from the cold-He was carrying his short spears and bull-hide buckler, and he had a cased bow on his back and a quiver at his hip, but only the veil mattered. This was no time for the Aiel to start killing. Twenty paces down slope toward the camp, thirty more Aielmen were squatting on their heels, holding their weapons casually.

wʌn ɪn θɹi hæɾ ɪz feɪs bɛɹ, soʊ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðə koʊld. wɪð il, jə kəd nɛvɝ bi ʃʊɹ, ðoʊ.

One in three had his face bare, so maybe it was the cold. With Aiel, you could never be sure, though.

kwɪkli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ sɛvɹəl əpɹoʊtʃɪz, bæʃɪɹ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɑn laɪtnəs. "ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd wəd nɑt laɪk ðæt, beɪl, ən ɪf juv fɝɡɑɾən wʌɾ ɪts laɪk biɪŋ ə jʌŋ mæn, ðət minz ɹænd ælθɹ woʊn laɪk ɪt."

Quickly considering several approaches, Bashere decided on lightness. "Elayne Trakand would not like that, Bael, and if you've forgotten what it's like being a young man, that means Rand al'Thor won't like it."

beɪl ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. "məleɪn toʊl mi wʌɾ ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən sɛd. wi mʌs də nʌθɪŋ ɑn əɹ pɑɹt. ðəɾ ɪz sɪmpəl-maɪndəd. wən ən ɛnəmi kʌmz əɡɛns ju, jə meɪk jus ə huɛvɝ wɪl dæns ðə spɪɹz baɪ jəɹ saɪd. də ðeɪ pleɪ ət wɔɹ ðə weɪ ðeɪ pleɪ ət ðɛɹ ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz?" "wi ɑɹ aʊtləndɝz, beɪl. ðət kaʊns ɪn ændɝ."

Bael grunted sourly. "Melaine told me what Elayne Trakand said. We must do nothing on her part. That is simple-minded. When an enemy comes against you, you make use of whoever will dance the spears by your side. Do they play at war the way they play at their Game of Houses?" "We are outlanders, Bael. That counts in Andor."

ðə hjudʒ ilmən ɡɹʌntɪɾ əɡɛn.

The huge Aielman grunted again.

ðəɹ sim noʊ pɔɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn ðə pɑlətɪks ɪnvɑlvd. aʊtlæn hɛlp kəd kɑst ɪleɪn wʌt ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡeɪn, ən əɹ ɛnəmiz nu ɪɾ ən nu ʃi nu ɪt, soʊ ðeɪ hæd noʊ fɪɹ ə bæʃɪɹ əɹ beɪl əɹ ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz. ɪn fækt, dɪspaɪt ðə sidʒ, boʊθ saɪdz wəd ɡoʊ tə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt tə əvɔɪd pɪtʃt bæɾəl. ɪt wɑz ə wɔɹ, bʌɾ ə mənuvɝ ən skɝmɪʃɪz ənlɛs sʌmwʌn blʌndɝd, ən ðə wɪnɝ wəd bi huɛvɝ ɡeɪn ən ʌnəseɪləbəl pəzɪʃən əɹ fɔɹs ði ʌðɝ ɪndə wʌn ðət kəd nɑt bi dɪfɛndəd. beɪl laɪkli wəd si ɪɾ əz noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm deɪz'

There seemed no point trying to explain the politics involved. Outland help could cost Elayne what she was trying to gain, and her enemies knew it and knew she knew it, so they had no fear of Bashere or Bael or the Legion of the Dragon, whatever their numbers. In fact, despite the siege, both sides would go to great effort to avoid pitched battle. It was a war, but of maneuver and skirmishes unless someone blundered, and the winner would be whoever gained an unassailable position or forced the other into one that could not be defended. Bael likely would see it as no different from Daes'

deɪmɑɹ. ɪn ɔl tʃɹuθ, bæʃɪɹ sɔ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə sɪməlɛɹəɾi hɪmsɛlf. wɪð ðə blaɪɾ ɑn ɪts dɔɹstɛp, sɑldɑiə kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd kɑntɛsts fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn-taɪɹəns kəd bi ɛndʒjʊɹd, ən ðə blaɪt sun kɪl ðə stupəɾ ən ðə ɡɹiɾi, bʌɾ ivən ðɪs pəkjuljɝ sɔɹɾ ə sɪvəl wɔɹ wəɾ əlaʊ ðə blaɪt tə kɪl sɑldɑiə.

Dae'mar. In all truth, Bashere saw a great deal of similarity himself. With the Blight on its doorstep, Saldaea could not afford contests for the throne-Tyrants could be endured, and the Blight soon killed the stupid and the greedy, but even this peculiar sort of civil war would allow the Blight to kill Saldaea.

hi ɹɪtɝn tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə kæmp θɹu hɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt haʊ ən ʌɾɝ ful laɪk ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn cʊɾə ɡeɪn ðə bækɪŋ ə nɑiən ɑɝɔnən ən ɛləniə sɑɝənd. ðət pɛɹ wɑz ɡɹiɾi ən æmbɪʃəs, itʃ ʌɾɝli kənvɪnst ə hɝ oʊn ɹaɪt tə ðə θɹoʊn, ən ɪf i ʌndɝstʊd ðə tæŋɡəld wɛb ændɔɹənz juz tə dɪsaɪd ðiz mæɾɝz, itʃ hæd fɑɹ bɛɾɝ kleɪm ðən ɛɹəmɪlə. wʊlvz ən wʊlfhnz wɝ nɔɹ ɪn ɪt. ðɪs wɑz wʊlvz dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ə læpdɔɡ. pɝhæps ɪleɪn nu ðə ɹizən, bʌt ʃi wəd bɛɹli ivən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ noʊts wɪð hɪm, bɹif ən ənɪnfɔɹməɾɪv.

He returned to studying the camp through his looking glass, trying to puzzle out how an utter fool like Arymilla Marne could have gained the backing of Naean Arawnand and Elenia Sarand. That pair was greedy and ambitious, each utterly convinced of her own right to the throne, and if he understood the tangled web Andorans used to decide these matters, each had far better claim than Arymilla. Wolves and wolfhounds were nor in it. This was wolves deciding to follow a lapdog. Perhaps Elayne knew the reason, but she would barely even exchange notes with him, brief and uninformative.

tu mʌtʃ tʃæns sʌmwʌn wəd lɝn ʌv ɪɾ ən θɪŋk ʃi wɑz plɑɾɪŋ wɪð hɪm. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi laɪk ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz.

Too much chance someone would learn of it and think she was plotting with him. it was very like the Game of Houses.

"sʌmwʌn ɪz gɑnə dæns ðə spɪɹz, ɪt simz," beɪl sɛd, ən bæʃɪɹ loʊɝd ði ɔɹneɪt tub lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə faɪnd wɛɹ ði ilmən wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ.

"Someone is going to dance the spears, it seems," Bael said, and Bashere lowered the ornate tube long enough to find where the Aielman was pointing.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ə pipəl fliɪŋ ðə sɪɾi əhɛɾ ə ðə sidʒ fəɹ deɪz, bʌt sʌmwʌn hæd lɛft ɪt tu leɪd. hæf ə dʌzən kænvəs-tɑpt wæɡənz stʊd hɔldɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɹoʊd dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ði ɛdʒ ə loʊ keɪməln, sɝaʊndəd baɪ fɪfti hɔɹsmən ʌndɝ ə blu-ænd-waɪt kɔɹɾɝd bænɝ ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə ʃoʊ ə ɹʌnɪŋ bɛɹ, əɹ meɪbi səm sɔɹɾ ə θɪk-bɑɾid haʊnd, wən ɪt ɹɪpəld ɪn ə sʌɾən wɪnd. dɪspɪɹəɾɪd foʊk hʌɾəld tə wʌn saɪd, klʌtʃɪŋ kloʊks ɝaʊn ðɛmsɛlvz, mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn, tʃɪlʒɹən klɪŋɪŋ tə wɪmənz skɝts. səm ə ðə hɔɹsmən hæd dɪsmaʊntɪd tə ɹænsæk ðə wæɡənz; tʃɛsts ən bɑksəz ən ivən wʌt lʊk tə bi kloʊðz ɔlɹɛɾi dɑɾəd ðə snoʊ.

There had been a steady stream of people fleeing the city ahead of the siege for days, but someone had left it too lade. Half a dozen canvas-topped wagons stood halded in the middle of the Tar Valon road just outside the edge of Low Caemyln, surrounded by fifty horsemen under a blue-and-white quartered banner that appeared to show a running bear, or maybe some sort of thick-bodied hound, when it rippled in a sudden wind. Dispirited folk huddled to one side, clutching cloaks around themselves, men with their heads down, children clinging to women's skirts. Some of the horsemen had dismounted to ransack the wagons; chests and boxes and even what looked to be clothes already dotted the snow.

laɪkli ðeɪ wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ kɔɪn əɹ dʒɹɪŋk ðoʊ ɛni ʌðɝ væljəbəl ðət tɝn ʌp wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə sʌmwʌnz sæɾəlbæɡz tu. sun ɪnʌf sʌmwʌn wəd kʌt fɹi ðə wæɡən timz, əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ wəd dʒʌs teɪk ðə wæɡənz. wæɡənz ən hɔɹsəz wɝ ɔlweɪz jusfəl fəɹ ən ɑɹmi, ən ðə pəkjuljɝ ɹulz ə ðɪs vɛɹi pəkjuljɝ ændɔɝən sɪvəl wɔɹ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə ɡɪv mʌtʃ pɹətɛkʃən tə ðoʊz u wɝ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ pleɪs ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm. bʌt ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts wɝ swɪŋɪŋ oʊpən, ən əz sun əz ðə ɡæp wɑz waɪɾ ɪnʌf, ɹɛd-koʊɾəd lænsɝz pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə twɛnti-fʊt haɪ ɑɹtʃ əɾ ə ɡæləp, sʌnlaɪt ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɑn læns-pɔɪns ən bɹɛstpleɪts ən hɛlməts, θʌndɝɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹoʊd bɪtwin ðə lɔŋ, ɛmpti mɑɹkəts.

Likely they were searching for coin or drink though any other valuable that turned up would go into someone's saddlebags too. Soon enough someone would cut free the wagon teams, or perhaps they would just take the wagons. Wagons and horses were always useful for an army, and the peculiar rules of this very peculiar Andoran civil war did not appear to give much protection to those who were in the wrong place at the wrong time. But the city gates were swinging open, and as soon as the gap was wide enough, red-coated lancers poured out of the twenty-foot high arch at a gallop, sunlight glittering on lance-points and breastplates and helmets, thundering down the road between the long, empty markets.

ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz wɝ kʌmɪŋ aʊt. ɪnʌf ə ðɛm, ɛniweɪ. bæʃɪɹ swʌŋ ɪz ɡlæs bæk tə ðə wæɡənz.

The Queen's Guards were coming out. Enough of them, anyway. Bashere swung his glass back to the wagons.

əpɛɹənli ði ɔfəsɝ ʌndɝ ðə bɛɹ, ɪf ə bɛɹ ɪt wɑz, hæd dʌn ɪz sʌmz ɔlɹɛɾi. fɪfti əɡɛns tu hʌnʒɹəd meɪd vɛɹi pʊɹ ɑdz, wɪð oʊnli ə fju wæɡənz ət steɪk. ðə mɛn u hæd dɪsmaʊntɪd wɝ bæk ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, ən ivən əz bæʃɪɹ faʊn ðɛm, ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm ɡæləpt əweɪ nɔɹθ təwɔɹd hɪm, ðə blu-ænd-waɪt bænɝ stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪts stæf-moʊst ə ðə pipəl hʌɾəld bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd stɛɹɾ æftɝ ðə dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz, ðɛɹ kənfjuʒən əz klɪɹ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌɾ ə fju ɪmiɾiətli ɹʌʃt tə bɪɡɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ skæɾɝd bɪlɔŋɪŋz aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ ən paɪlɪŋ əm bæk ɪndə ðə wæɡənz.

Apparently the officer under the bear, if a bear it was, had done his sums already. Fifty against two hundred made very poor odds, with only a few wagons at stake. The men who had dismounted were back in their saddles, and even as Bashere found them, the lot of them galloped away north toward him, the blue-and-white banner streaming behind its staff-Most of the people huddled beside the road stared after the departing soldiers, their confusion as clear as if he had been able to make out their faces, but a few immediately rushed to begin gathering up their scattered belongings out of the snow and piling them back into the wagons.

ði ɝaɪvəl ə ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɹeɪn ɝaʊn ðə wæɡənz ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, pʊɾ ə kwɪk ɛn tə ðæt. ɡɑɹdzmɪn kwɪkli bɪɡæn hɝɾɪŋ pipəl təwɔɹd ðə wæɡənz-sʌm stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə dɑɹt pæst əm fəɹ səm pɹaɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋ, ən wʌn mæn bɪɡæn weɪvɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst əɾ ə ɡɑɹdzmæn, ən ɑbviəs ɔfəsɝ wɪð waɪt plumz ɑn ɪz hɛlməɾ ən ə ɹɛd sæʃ əkɹɔs ɪz bɹɛstpleɪt, bʌt ði ɔfəsɝ lin fɹəm ðə sæɾəl ən bækhændəd ðə pɹoʊtɛstɝ ɪn ðə feɪs. ðə fɛloʊ wɛn daʊn ɑn ɪz bæk laɪk ə stoʊn, ən æftɝ wʌn fɹoʊzən moʊmənt, ɛvɹiwʌn u wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɑntu ðə wæɡənz wɛn skɝiɪŋ, ɪksɛpt ə pɛɹ ə mɛn u pɔz tə pɪk ʌp ðə fɔlən mæn baɪ hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən hilz, ən ðeɪ hɝiɾ əz bɛs ðeɪ kəd kæɹiɪŋ ɪz lɪmp weɪt, ə wʊmən ʌp ɑn ðə læst wæɡən ɪn laɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi læʃɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ɡɛɾ əɹ tim tɝn ɝaʊn ən hɛɾəd bæk təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi.

The arrival of the Guardsmen, drawing rein around the wagons a few minutes later, put a quick end to that. Guardsmen quickly began herding people toward the wagons-Some still tried to dart past them for some prized belonging, and one man began waving his arms in protest at a Guardsman, an obvious officer with white plumes on his helmet and a red sash across his breastplate, but the officer leaned from the saddle and backhanded the protester in the face. The fellow went down on his back like a stone, and after one frozen moment, everyone who was not already scrambling onto the wagons went scurrying, except a pair of men who paused to pick up the fallen man by his shoulders and heels, and they hurried as best they could carrying his limp weight, A woman up on the last wagon in line was already lashing her reins to get her team turned around and headed back toward the city.

bæʃɪɹ loʊɝd ðə ɡlæs tə stʌɾi ðə kæmp, ðən pɹɛst ɪt bæk tə hɪz aɪ fəɹ ə kloʊsɝ lʊk.

Bashere lowered the glass to study the camp, then pressed it back to his eye for a closer look.

mɛn wɝ stɪl dɪɡɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ʃʌvəl ən mætɑk, ən ʌðɝz ɹɛslɪŋ sæks ən bæɹəlz daʊn fɹəm wæɡənz. noʊbəlz ən ɔfəsɝz wɔk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz əbaʊt ðə kæmp, kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðə wɝk. ɔl kɑm əz kæɾəl ɪn pæstʃɝ. faɪnəli, sʌmwʌn pɔɪntəd kaʊɝd ðə ɹaɪz bɪtwin əm ən ðə sɪɾi, ðən ənʌðɝ ən ənʌðɝ, ən maʊntəd mɛn bɪɡæn tə tʃɹɑt, pleɪnli ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. ðə bɛɹ-bænɝ wɑz dʒʌs kʌmɪŋ ɪndə saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp ɑn ðə haɪt.

Men were still digging away with shovel and mattock, and others wrestling sacks and barrels down from wagons. Nobles and officers walked their horses about the camp, keeping an eye on the work. All calm as cattle in pasture. Finally, someone pointed coward the rise between them and the city, then another and another, and mounted men began to trot, plainly shouting orders. The bear-banner was just coming into sight of the camp on the height.

tʌkɪŋ ðə ɡlæs bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹm, bæʃɪɹ fɹaʊnd. ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðə haɪ ɡɹaʊn tə wɔɹn əm ʌv wʌt maɪt bi hæpənɪŋ bɪɑn ðɛɹ saɪt. ivən ɪn ðə sɝɾənti noʊ wʌn wɑz gɑnə ɔfɝ bæɾəl ðət wɑz stupəd. ɪt maɪɾ ɔlsoʊ bi jusfəl, ɪf ði ʌðɝ kæmps wɝ əz kɛɹləs, ən ɪf noʊ wʌn kɝɛktəd ðə mɪsteɪk. hi pʌft ɪɹɪɾəbli θɹu hɪz mʌstæʃɪz. ɪf i hæd bɪn gɑnə faɪt ðə bɪsiɡɝz.

Tucking the glass beneath his arm, Bashere frowned. They had no guards on the high ground to warn them of what might be happening beyond their sight. Even in the certainty no one was going to offer battle that was stupid. It might also be useful, if the other camps were as careless, and if no one corrected the mistake. He puffed irritably through his mustaches. If he had been going to fight the besiegers.

ə ɡlæns ʃoʊɾ ɪm ðə wæɡənz hæfweɪ bæk tə ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɡeɪt wɪð ðɛɹ ɛskɔɹɾ ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn, ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz læʃɪŋ ðɛɹ timz əz ɪt pɝsut wɝ bɹiðɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ nɛks. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ði ɔfəsɝ wɪð ðə sæʃ, hu wɑz weɪvɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd fəɹ səm ɹizən.

A glance showed him the wagons halfway back to the Tar Valon Gate with their escort of Guardsmen, the wagon drivers lashing their teams as it pursuit were breathing down their necks. Or maybe it was just the officer with the sash, who was waving his sword over his head for some reason.

"ðɛɹəl bi noʊ dænsɪŋ tədeɪ," hi sɛd.

"There'll be no dancing today," he said.

"ðɛn aɪ hæv bɛɾɝ tə də wɪð maɪ deɪ ðən wɑtʃ wɛtləndɝz dɪɡ hoʊlz," beɪl ɹɪplaɪd, "meɪ jə ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd, dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ"

"Then I have better to do with my day than watch wetlanders dig holes," Bael replied, "May you always find water and shade, Davram Bashere"

"æt ðə moʊmənt, aɪd ɹæðɝ əv dʒɹaɪ fiɾ ən ə wɔɹm faɪɝ," bæʃɪɹ mʌɾɝd wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ!

"At the moment, I'd rather have dry feet and a warm fire," Bashere muttered without thinking!

ðən wɪʃt i hæd nɑt. stɛp ɑn ə mænz fɔɹmæləɾi ən i maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ju, ən ði il wɝ fɔɹməl ən stʃɹeɪnʒ bɪsaɪdz.

Then wished he had not. Step on a man's formality and he might try to kill you, and the Aiel were formal and strange besides.

bʌt beɪl θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft. "ðə wɛt-lænz tɝn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn ɪts hɛd dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ." ə kjʊɹiəs dʒɛstʃɝ ə hɪz ɹaɪt hæn bɹɔt ði ʌðɝ il tə ðɛɹ fit, ən ðeɪ loʊpt ɔf istwɝɾ ɪn lɔŋ, izi stʃɹaɪdz. ðə snoʊ dɪd nɑt sim tə ɡɪv əm ɛni dɪfəkəlti.

But Bael threw back his head and laughed. "The wet-lands turn everything on its head Davram Bashere." A curious gesture of his right hand brought the other Aiel to their feet, and they loped off eastward in long, easy strides. The snow did not seem to give them any difficulty.

slaɪɾɪŋ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ɪndə ðə lɛðɝ keɪs hæŋɪŋ fɹəm kwɪks sæɾəlboʊ, bæʃɪɹ maʊntəɾ ən tɝn ðə beɪ wɛst. hɪz oʊn ɛskɔɹt hæd bɪn weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝs sloʊp, ən ðeɪ fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð oʊnli ðə feɪn kɹik ə lɛðɝ ən nɛvɝ ə dʒɪŋɡəl ʌv ʌnsɪkjʊɹd mɛɾəl. ðeɪ nʌmbɝd fjuɝ ðən beɪlz ɛskɔɹt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ tʌf mɛn fɹəm ɪz ɪsteɪts ət tɪɹ, ən i hæd lɛɾ əm ɪndə ðə blaɪt mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ əm saʊθ. ɛvɹi mæn hæɾ ɪz əsaɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪl tə wɑtʃ, əhɛɾ əɹ bɪhaɪnd, lɛft əɹ ɹaɪt, haɪ əɹ loʊ, ən ðɛɹ hɛdz swɪvəl kɑnstənli. hi hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dʒʌst ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə moʊʃənz. ðə fɔɹəst wɑz spɑɹs hɪɹ, ɛvɹi bɹæntʃ bɛɹ ɪksɛpt ɑn oʊk ən lɛðɝlif paɪn ən fɝ, bʌt ðə snoʊ-kʌvɝd læn ɹoʊl soʊ ðəɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd maʊntəd mɛn kəd bi fɪfti peɪsɪz əweɪ ən ənsin. nɑt ðəɾ i ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛni sətʃ θɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, wʌt kɪl jə wɑz ɔlweɪz wʌt jə nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hi izd ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. jə dʒʌs hæd tə ɪkspɛk ði ʌnɪkspɛktɪd.

Sliding his looking glass into the leather case hanging from Quick's saddlebow, Bashere mounted and turned the bay west. His own escort had been waiting on the reverse slope, and they fell in behind him with only the faint creak of leather and never a jingle of unsecured metal. They numbered fewer than Bael's escort, but they were tough men from his estates at Tyr, and he had led them into the Blight many times before bringing them south. Every man had his assigned part of the trail to watch, ahead or behind, left or right, high or low, and their heads swiveled constantly. He hoped they were not just going through the motions. The forest was sparse here, every branch bare except on oak and leatherleaf pine and fir, but the snow-covered land rolled so that a hundred mounted men could be fifty paces away and unseen. Not that he expected any such thing, but then, what killed you was always what you never expected. Unconsciously, he eased his sword in its scabbard. You just had to expect the unexpected.

tuməd hæd kəmæn ə ði ɛskɔɹt, əz i dɪd moʊs deɪz bæʃɪɹ dɪd nɑɾ əv sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ ðə jʌŋ lutɛnən tə du. hi kəd θɪŋk klɪɹli ən si bɪɑnd wʌt wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm; hi wɑz dɛstɪn fəɹ haɪɝ ɹæŋk, ɪf i lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf. ə tɔl mæn, ɪf ə kʌpəl ə hænz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən beɪl, tədeɪ hi wɔɹ dɪsɡɹʌntəlmən ɑn ɪz feɪs laɪk ə sɛkənd noʊz.

Tumad had command of the escort, as he did most days Bashere did not have something more important for the young lieutenant to do. He could think clearly and see beyond what was in front of him; he was destined for higher rank, if he lived long enough. A tall man, if a couple of hands shorter than Bael, today he wore disgruntlement on his face like a second nose.

"wʌt tʃɹʌbəlz ju, tuməd?"

"What troubles you, Tumad?"

"ði ilmən wɑz ɹaɪt, maɪ lɔɹd." tuməd tʌɡd æŋɡɹəli əɾ ɪz θɪk blæk bɪɹd wɪð ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst, "ðiz ændɔɹənz spɪɾ əɾ əɹ fit. aɪ də nɑt laɪk hævɪŋ tə ɹaɪɾ əweɪ waɪl ðeɪ θʌm ən ɪɹ əɾ ʌs" wɛl i wɑz stɪl jʌŋ.

"The Aielman was right, my Lord." Tumad tugged angrily at his thick black beard with a gauntleted fist, "These Andorans spit at our feet. I do not like having to ride away while they thumb an ear at us" Well he was still young.

"ju faɪn əɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən bɔɹɪŋ, pɝhæps?" bæʃɪɹ læft. "ju nid mɔɹ ɪksaɪtmənt?

"You find our situation boring, perhaps?" Bashere laughed. "You need more excitement?

tɛnoʊbiə ɪz oʊnli fɪfti liɡz nɔɹθ ʌv ʌs, ən ɪf ɹumɝ kən bi bɪlivd, ʃi bɹɔɾ ɛθɛniɛl ə kændɝ ən peɪɾə ʌv ɝæfəl ən ivən ðət ʃaɪnɝən isɑɹ wɪð hɝ. ɔl ðə maɪɾ ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs, tuməd. ðoʊz ændɔɹənz daʊn ɪn mʊɹændi doʊn laɪk əs biɪŋ ɪn ændɝ, iðɝ, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ, ən ɪf ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹmi ðəɹ feɪsɪŋ dʌzn tʃɑp əm tə pisəz, əɹ hæzən ɔlɹɛɾi ðeɪ meɪ kʌm lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs. soʊ meɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. wiv ɹɪɾən fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən aɪ kæn si ɛni sɪstɝ fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðæt. ən ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ ðə sintʃæn, tuməd. dʒju ɹɪli θɪŋk wiv sin ðə læst ə ðɛm? ðəl kʌm tə ʌs, əɹ wɪl əv tə ɡoʊ tə ðɛm; wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ ɪz ʃʊɹ. jə jʌŋ mɛn doʊnt noʊ ɪksaɪtmənt wən ɪts kɹɔlɪŋ ɪn jəɹ mʌstæʃ!" kwaɪət tʃʌkəlz ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə mɛn fɑloʊɪŋ, mɛn əz oʊld əz bæʃɪɹ hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ən ivən tuməd flæʃt waɪt tiθ θɹu hɪz bɪɹɾ ɪn ə ɡɹɪn. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bɪn ɑn kæmpeɪn bɪfɔɹ, ɪf nɛvɝ wʌn soʊ ɑɾ əz ðɪs. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ɝaʊnd, bæʃɪɹ wɑtʃt ðə weɪ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, bʌt wɪð oʊnli hæf ɪz ətɛnʃən.

Tenobia is only fifty leagues north of us, and if rumor can be believed, she brought Ethenielle of Kandor and Paita of Arafel and even that Shienaran Easar with her. All the might of the Borderlands come looking for us, Tumad. Those Andorans down in Murandy don't like us being in Andor, either, so I hear, and if that Aes Sedai army they're facing doesn't chop them to pieces, or hasn't already they may come looking for us. So may the Aes Sedai, for that matter, sooner or later. We've ridden for the Dragon Reborn, and I can't see any sister forgetting that. And then there are the Seanchan, Tumad. Do you really think we've seen the last of them? They will come to us, or we will have to go to them; one or the other is sure. You young men don't know excitement when it's crawling in your mustache!" Quiet chuckles rippled through the men following, men as old as Bashere himself for the most part, and even Tumad flashed white teeth through his beard in a grin. They had all been on campaign before, if never one so odd as this. Straightening around, Bashere watched the way through the trees, but with only half his attention.

ɪn ɔl tʃɹuθ, tɛnoʊbiə dɪd wɝi hɪm. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu waɪ isɑɹ ən ði ʌðɝz hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ təɡɛðɝ, mʌtʃ lɛs stʃɹɪp əweɪ əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz əz hɪɹseɪ sɛd ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt saʊθ. ivən hɪɹseɪ dɪvaɪɾəd baɪ hæf. daʊtləs ðeɪ hæd ɹizənz ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝd ɡʊɾ ən səfɪʃənt, ən daʊtləs tɛnoʊbiə ʃɛɹd ðɛm. bʌɾ i nu hɝ; hi hæd tɔɾ əɹ tə ɹaɪd, wɑtʃt əɹ ɡɹoʊ ʌp, pɹizɛntəɾ əɹ ðə bɹoʊkən kɹaʊn wən ʃi tʊk ðə θɹoʊn. ʃi wɑz ə ɡʊd ɹulɝ, niðɝ tu hɛvi-hændəd nɔɹ ku laɪt, ɪntɛlədʒən ɪf nɑɾ ɔlweɪz waɪz, bɹeɪv wɪθaʊt biɪŋ fulhɑɹɾi, bʌɾ ɪmpʌlsɪv wɑz ə maɪl dɪskɹɪpʃən ə hɝ. səmtaɪmz "hɑt-hɛɾəd" wɑz maɪld. ən i wɑz əz ʃʊɹ əz i kəd bi ðət ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɡoʊl əsaɪd fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ ði ʌðɝz eɪmd æt. ðə hɛɾ ə dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ. ɪf ðət wɑz soʊ, ʃi wɑz ənlaɪkli tə sɛɾəl fəɹ ənʌðɝ pɪɹiəɾ ʌv ɛɡzaɪl, æftɝ kʌmɪŋ ðɪs fɑɹ. ðə lɔŋɡɝ tɛnoʊbiə wɝiɾ ə boʊn ɪn əɹ tiθ, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ɪt wɑz tə kənvɪns əɹ tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp. ɪt wɑz ə nit pɹɑbləm. ʃi ʃəd bi ɪn sɑldɑiə ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ, bʌt soʊ ʃəd hi. ʃi kəd kənvɪkt ɪm ə tʃɹizən twaɪs oʊvɝ ət lis fəɹ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn sɪns kʌmɪŋ saʊθ, bʌɾ i stɪl kəd si noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ tə hæv ɡɔn. ɹɪbɛljən-tɛnoʊbiə kəd dɪfaɪn ðət lusli wən ʃi tʃoʊz-ɹɪbɛljən wɑz hɔɹəbəl tə kɑntəmpleɪt, jɛɾ i wɑntəɾ ɪz hɛd fɝmli ətætʃt tə hɪz nɛk ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ. ə niɾ ən θɔɹni pɹɑbləm.

In all truth, Tenobia did worry him. The Light only knew why Easar and the others had decided to leave the Blightborder together, much less strip away as many soldiers as hearsay said they had brought south. Even hearsay divided by half. Doubtless they had reasons they considered good and sufficient, and doubtless Tenobia shared them. But he knew her; he had taught her to ride, watched her grow up, presented her the Broken Crown when she took the throne. She was a good ruler, neither too heavy-handed nor coo light, intelligent if not always wise, brave without being foolhardy, but impulsive was a mild description of her. Sometimes "hot-headed" was mild. And he was as sure as he could be that she had her own goal aside from whatever the others aimed at. The head of Davram Bashere. If that was so, she was unlikely to settle for another period of exile, after coming this far. The longer Tenobia worried a bone in her teeth, the harder it was to convince her to give it up. It was a neat problem. She should be in Saldaea guarding the Blightborder, but so should he. She could convict him of treason twice over at least for what he had done since coming south, but he still could see no other way to have gone. Rebellion-Tenobia could define that loosely when she chose-rebellion was horrible to contemplate, yet he wanted his head firmly attached to his neck a while longer. A neat and thorny problem.

ði ɛnkæmpmən kənteɪnɪŋ ði eɪt θaʊzənd-ɑd laɪt kævəlɹi hi hæd lɛft æftɝ ɪljən ən ðə sintʃæn spɹɛd waɪɾɝ ðən ðə kæmp bæk ɑn ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɹoʊd, bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi sɛd tə spɹɔl.

The encampment containing the eight thousand-odd light cavalry he had left after Illian and the Seanchan spread wider than the camp back on the Tar Valon Road, but it could not be said to sprawl.

ðə hɔɹslaɪnz wɝ junəfɔɹm ɹoʊz wɪð ə fɛɹiɝz fɔɹdʒ əɾ iðɝ ɛnd, stʃɹɛtʃt bɪtwin ikwəli stʃɹeɪt ɹoʊz ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹeɪ əɹ ʃɛl-waɪt tɛns, ðoʊ ðoʊz ʃoʊɾ ə ɡʊd mɛni pætʃəz, naʊ. ɛvɹi mæn kəd bi maʊntəɾ ən ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə kaʊn ə fɪfti fɹəm ə tʃɹʌmpət sɪɡnəl, ən ɪz sɛntʃɹiz wɝ pleɪs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hæd ðət kaʊn ən mɔɹ. ivən ðə kæmp-fɑloʊɝz' tɛns ən wæɡənz, ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz saʊθ ə ðə ɹɛst, wɝ mɔɹ ɔɹɾɝli ðən ðə soʊlʒɝz' bɪsidʒɪŋ ðə sɪɾi əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd fɑloʊd ði ɪɡzæmpəl ə ðə sɑldəiənz. sʌmwʌt, ət list.

The horselines were uniform rows with a farrier's forge at either end, stretched between equally straight rows of large gray or shell-white tents, though those showed a good many patches, now. Every man could be mounted and ready to ride inside a count of fifty from a trumpet signal, and his sentries were placed to make sure they had that count and more. Even the camp-followers' tents and wagons, a hundred paces south of the rest, were more orderly than the soldiers' besieging the city as though they had followed the example of the Saldaeans. Somewhat, at least.

əz i ɹoʊɾ ɪn wɪð ɪz ɛskɔɹt, mɛn muv kwɪkli ən ɡɹɪmli əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðə sɪɡnəl tə maʊn hæd bɪn saʊndəd. mɔɹ ðən wʌn hæɾ ɪz sɔɹd dʒɹɔn. vɔɪsəz kɔl tə hɪm, bʌɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ kɹaʊɾ ə mɛn ən wɪmən, moʊsli wɪmən, ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kæmp, hi fɛlt ə sʌɾən nʌmnəs ɪnsaɪd. hi dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz, ən kwɪk spɹæŋ fɔɹwɝɾ əɾ ə ɡæləp. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn fɑloʊɾ ɪm əɹ nɑt. hi hɝd nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə blʌd paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, sɔ noʊ θɪŋ bʌt ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz oʊn ʃɑɹp-pik tɛnt. ðə tɛn i ʃɛɹd wɪð dʒɹə.

As he rode in with his escort, men moved quickly and grimly among the horselines, almost as if the signal to mount had been sounded. More than one had his sword drawn. Voices called to him, but at the sight of a large crowd of men and women, mostly women, gathered in the center of the camp, he felt a sudden numbness inside. He dug in his heels, and Quick sprang forward at a gallop. He did not know whether anyone followed him or not. He heard nothing but the blood pounding in his ears, saw no thing but the crowd in front of his own sharp-peaked tent. The tent he shared with Deira.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹeɪn ɪn ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə kɹaʊd, dʒʌs θɹu hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl ən hɪt ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹʌnɪŋ. hi hɝd pipəl spik wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪn wʌt ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ. ðeɪ pɑɹɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, oʊpənɪŋ ə pæθ tə hɪz tɛnt, əɹ i wʊɾə ɹʌn əm oʊvɝ.

He did not rein in on reaching the crowd, just threw himself out of the saddle and hit the ground running. He heard people speak without taking in what they were saying. They parted in front of him, opening a path to his tent, or he would have run them over.

dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛntflæps, hi hɔltəd. ðə tɛnt, lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf fəɹ twɛnti soʊlʒɝz tə slip ɪn, wɑz kɹaʊɾəd tə ðə wɔlz wɪð wɪmən, waɪvz ə noʊbəlz ən ɔfəsɝz, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz kwɪkli faʊn ɪz oʊn waɪf, dʒɹə, siɾəd ɑn ə foʊldɪŋ tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɑɹpəts ðət sɝvd əz ə flɔɹ, ən ðə nʌmnəs feɪɾəd. hi nu ʃi wəd daɪ wʌn deɪ-ðeɪ boʊθ wʊd-bʌt ði oʊnli θɪŋ i fɪɹd wɑz lɪvɪŋ wɪθaʊt hɝ. ðən i ɹilaɪz ðət səm ə ðə wɪmən wɝ hɛlpɪŋ əɹ tə loʊɝ əɹ dʒɹɛs tə hɝ weɪst. ənʌðɝ wɑz pɹɛsɪŋ ə foʊldəd klɔθ tə dʒɹəz lɛft ɑɹm, ən ðə klɔθ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹɛɾ əz blʌd ɹæn daʊn əɹ ɑɹm ɪn ə ʃiɾ ən dʒɹɪp fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪndə ə boʊl sɛɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹpət. ðəɹ wɑz ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl əmaʊn ə dɑɹk blʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə boʊl.

Just inside the tentflaps, he halted. The tent, large enough for twenty soldiers to sleep in, was crowded to the walls with women, wives of nobles and officers, but his eyes quickly found his own wife, Deira, seated on a folding chair in the middle of the carpets that served as a floor, and the numbness faded. He knew she would die one day-they both would-but the only thing he feared was living without her. Then he realized that some of the women were helping her to lower her dress to her waist. Another was pressing a folded cloth to Deira's left arm, and the cloth was growing red as blood ran down her arm in a sheet and dripped from her fingers into a bowl set on the carpet. There was a considerable amount of dark blood already in the bowl.

ʃi sɔ hɪm ət ðə seɪm ɪnstənt, ən əɹ aɪz flæʃt ɪn ə feɪs ðət wɑz mʌtʃ tu peɪl. "ɪt kʌmz fɹəm haɪɹɪŋ aʊtləndɝz, hʌzbənd," ʃi sɛd fɪɹsli, hɝ ɹaɪt hænd ʃeɪkɪŋ ə lɔŋ dæɡɝ ət hɪm.

She saw him at the same instant, and her eyes flashed in a face that was much too pale. "It comes from hiring outlanders, husband," she said fiercely, her right hand shaking a long dagger at him.

əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn, ɪntʃəz kɔlɝ ðən hi, ən bjuɾəfəl, hɝ feɪs fɹeɪmd wɪð ɹeɪvən hɛɹ wɪŋd wɪð waɪt, ʃi hæɾ ə kəmændɪŋ pɹɛzəns ðət kəd bɪkʌm ɪmpɪɹiəs wən ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi. ivən wən ʃi ɑbviəsli kəd bɛɹli sɪɾ əpɹaɪt. moʊst wɪmən wʊɾə bɪn flʌstɝɾ ət biɪŋ bɛɹ tə ðə weɪst ɪn fɹʌn ə soʊ mɛni, wɪð əɹ hʌzbən pɹɛzənt. nɑt dʒɹə. "ɪf jə dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɪnsɪst ɑn muvɪŋ laɪk ðə wɪnd, wi kəɾ əv ɡʊd mɛn fɹəm əɹ oʊn ɪsteɪts tə də wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nidfəl."

As tall as most men, inches caller than he, and beautiful, her face framed with raven hair winged with white, she had a commanding presence that could become imperious when she was angry. Even when she obviously could barely sit upright. Most women would have been flustered at being bare to the waist in front of so many, with her husband present. Not Deira. "If you did not always insist on moving like the wind, we could have good men from our own estates to do whatever was needful."

"ə dɪspjut wɪð sɝvəns, dʒɹə?" hi sɛd, kɑkɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt jud stɑɹt teɪkɪŋ naɪvz tə ðɛm." sɛvɹəl ə ðə wɪmən ɡeɪv ɪm kul, saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz. nɑɾ ɛvɹi mæn ən waɪf dɛl təɡɛðɝ əz i ən dʒɹə dɪd. səm θɔɾ əm ɑd sɪns ðeɪ sɛldəm ʃaʊɾəd.

"A dispute with servants, Deira?" he said, cocking an eyebrow. "I never thought you'd start taking knives to them." Several of the women gave him cool, sidelong glances. Not every man and wife dealt together as he and Deira did. Some thought them odd since they seldom shouted.

dʒɹə skaʊld ət hɪm, ðən ɡɹʌntɪɾ ə ʃɔɹt, ɪnvɑləntɛɹi læf. "aɪ wɪl stɑɹɾ ət ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ dævɹæm. ən ɡoʊ sloʊli, soʊ jə kən ʌndɝstænd, ʃi æɾəd wɪð ə smɔl smaɪl, pɔzɪŋ tə θæŋk ðə wɪmən u dʒɹeɪpt ə waɪt lɪnən ʃiɾ ɝaʊn əɹ bɛɹ tɔɹsoʊ. "aɪ ɹɪtɝn fɹəm maɪ ɹaɪd tə faɪn tu stʃɹeɪnʒ mɛn ɹænsækɪŋ əɹ tɛnt. ðeɪ dʒɹu dæɡɝz, soʊ nætʃɹəli, aɪ hɪt wʌn ə ðɛm wɪð ə tʃɛɹ ən stæb ði ʌðɝ." ʃi dɝɛktəɾ ə ɡɹɪmɑs əɾ əɹ kʌɾ ɑɹm. "nɑt wɛl ɪnʌf, sɪns i mænədʒ tə tʌtʃ mi. ðən zæviən ən səm ə ði ʌðɝz keɪm ɪn, ən ðə pɛɹ flɛd θɹu ə slɪt ðeɪ hæd meɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə tɛnt."

Deira scowled at him, then grunted a short, involuntary laugh. "I will start at the beginning Davram. And go slowly, so you can understand, she added with a small smile, pausing to thank the women who draped a white linen sheet around her bare torso. "I returned from my ride to find two strange men ransacking our tent. They drew daggers, so naturally, I hit one of them with a chair and stabbed the other." She directed a grimace at her cut arm. "Not well enough, since he managed to touch me. Then Zavion and some of the others came in, and the pair fled through a slit they had made in the rear of the tent."

sɛvɹəl ə ðə wɪmən nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli ən ɡɹɪp ðə hɪls ə ðə dæɡɝz ðeɪ ɔl wɔɹ. əntɪl dʒɹə sɛd dɑɹkli "aɪ toʊld əm tə ɡɪv tʃeɪs, bʌt ðeɪ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn tɛndɪŋ maɪ skɹætʃ." hænz dʒɹɑpt əweɪ fɹəm hɪls, ən feɪsəz kʌlɝd, ðoʊ nʌn lʊkt ɪn ðə list əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk fəɹ dɪsəbɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪn ə tɪkəlɪʃ pəzɪʃən. dʒɹə wɑz ðɛɹ lidʒ leɪɾi əz i wɑz ðɛɹ lidʒ lɔɹd, bʌt wɛðɝ əɹ nɔɹ ʃi kɔld ɪɾ ə skɹætʃ, ʃi cʊɾə blɛd tə dɛθ ɪf ðeɪ hæd lɛft əɹ tə ɡoʊ tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə θivz. "ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "aɪ ɔɹɾɝd ə sɝtʃ. ðeɪ woʊn bi hɑɹd tə faɪnd. wʌn əz ə lʌmp ɑn ɪz hɛd, ən ði ʌðɝ ɪz bliɾɪŋ." ʃi ɡeɪv ə ʃɑɹp, sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd.

Several of the women nodded grimly and gripped the hilts of the daggers they all wore. Until Deira said darkly "I told them to give chase, but they insisted on tending my scratch." Hands dropped away from hilts, and faces colored, though none looked in the least apologetic for disobeying. They had been in a ticklish position. Deira was their liege lady as he was their liege lord, but whether or nor she called it a scratch, she could have bled to death if they had left her to go chasing the thieves. "In any event," she went on, "I ordered a search. They won't be hard to find. One has a lump on his head, and the other is bleeding." She gave a sharp, satisfied nod.

zæviən, ðə sɪnjui, ɹɛd-hɛɹd leɪɾi ʌv ɡəhɔɹ, hɛld ʌp ə θɹɛɾəd niɾəl "ənlɛs juv teɪkən ʌp ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɪmbɹɔɪɾɝ maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi sɛd kuli, "meɪ aɪ sədʒɛs ðət jə wɪðdʒɹɔ." bæʃɪɹ ækwiɛst wɪð ə smɔl baʊ ʌv ɪz hɛd. dʒɹə nɛvɝ laɪkt ɪm tə wɑtʃ əɹ biɪŋ soʊn ʌp. hi nɛvɝ laɪkt wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ biɪŋ soʊn ʌp. aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛnt, hi pɔz tə ənaʊns ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs ðəɾ ɪz leɪɾi waɪf wɑz wɛl ən biɪŋ tɛndəd, ən ðət ðeɪ ʃəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs.

Zavion, the sinewy, red-haired Lady of Gahaur, held up a threaded needle "Unless you have taken up an interest in embroider my Lord," she said coolly, "may I suggest that you withdraw." Bashere acquiesced with a small bow of his head. Deira never liked him to watch her being sewn up. He never liked watching her being sewn up. Outside the tent, he paused to announce in a loud voice that his lady wife was well and being tended, and that they should all go on about their business.

ðə mɛn dɪpɑɹɾəd wɪð wɪʃɪz fəɹ dʒɹəz wɛl biɪŋ, bʌt nʌn ə ðə wɪmən stɝɾ ə fʊt. hi dɪd nɑt pɹɛs ðɛm. ðeɪ wəd ɹɪmeɪn əntɪl dʒɹə hɝsɛlf əpɪɹd, wʌtɛvɝ i sɛd, ən ə waɪz mæn tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd bæɾəlz i wəd nɑɾ oʊnli luz, bʌt lʊk fulɪʃ luzɪŋ.

The men departed with wishes for Deira's well being, but none of the women stirred a foot. He did not press them. They would remain until Deira herself appeared, whatever he said, and a wise man tried to avoid battles he would not only lose, but look foolish losing.

tuməd wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kɹaʊd, ən i fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd bæʃɪɹ, hu wɔkt wɪð ɪz hænz klæsp taɪtli bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hi hæd bɪn ɪkspɛktɪŋ ðɪs, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk, fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪɡʌn tə θɪŋk ɪt wəd nɑt hæpən. ən i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd dʒɹə tə nɪɹli daɪ kəz ʌv ɪt.

Tumad was waiting on the edge of the crowd, and he fell in beside Bashere, who walked with his hands clasped tightly behind his back. He had been expecting this, or something like, for a long time, but he had almost begun to think it would not happen. And he had never expected Deira to nearly die because of it.

"ðə tu mɛn əv bɪn faʊn maɪ lɔɹd," tuməd sɛd. "æt list, ðeɪ əpɛɹənli mit ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən ðə leɪɾi dʒɹə ɡeɪv." bæʃɪɹz hɛd dʒɝkt ɝaʊnd, mɝɾɝ ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən ðə jʌŋɡɝ mæn kwɪkli æɾəd, "ðeɪ wɝ dɛd, maɪ lɔɹd, dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə kæmp. itʃ ɡɑt wʌn θɹʌst wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ bleɪd." hi stæbd ə ɹɪŋɝ ət ðə beɪs ə hɪz skʌl, dʒʌs bɪhaɪn ði ɪɹ. "ɪt hæd tə bi mɔɹ ðən wʌn dɪɾ ɪt, ənlɛs i wɑz fæstɝ ðən ə ɹɑk vaɪpɝ."

"The two men have been found my Lord," Tumad said. "At least, they apparently meet the description the Lady Deira gave." Bashere's head jerked around, murder on his face, and the younger man quickly added, "They were dead, my Lord, just outside the camp. Each got one thrust with a narrow blade." He stabbed a ringer at the base of his skull, just behind the ear. "It had to be more than one did it, unless he was faster than a rock viper."
