bæʃɪɹ nɑɾəd. ðə pɹaɪs ə feɪljɝ ɔfən wɑz dɛθ. tu tə sɝtʃ, ən haʊ mɛni tə saɪləns ðɛm? haʊ mɛni ɹɪmeɪnd, ən haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn? wɝst ʌv ɔl, hu wɑz bɪhaɪn ɪt? ðə waɪt taʊɝ? ðə fɔɹseɪkən? ɪt simd ə dɪsɪʒən hæd bɪn ɹitʃt fəɹ hɪm. noʊ wʌn ɪksɛpt: tuməd wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ hɪm, bʌɾ i spoʊk sɔfli ɛniweɪ, ən tʃoʊz ɪz wɝdz kɔʃəsli. səmtaɪmz, ðə pɹaɪs ə kɛɹləsnəs wɑz dɛθ, tu. "ju noʊ wɛɹ tə faɪn ðə mæn u keɪm tə mi jɛstɝdeɪ?

Bashere nodded. The price of failure often was death. Two to search, and how many to silence them? How many remained, and how long before they tried again? Worst of all, who was behind it? The White Tower? The Forsaken? It seemed a decision had been reached for him. No one except: Tumad was close enough to hear him, but he spoke softly anyway, and chose his words cautiously. Sometimes, the price of carelessness was death, too. "You know where to find the man who came to me yesterday?

faɪn hɪm, ən tɛl ɪm aɪ əɡɹi, bʌt ðəɹ wɪl bi ə fju mɔɹ ðən wi tɔkt əbaʊt." ðə laɪt fɛðɝi snoʊ fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðə sɪɾi ʌv kɛɹhin dɪm ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪɾ oʊnli ə lɪɾəl, dʒʌs mjuɾɪŋ ðə bɹaɪtnəs. fɹəm ðə tɔl nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊ ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs, fɪɾəd wɪð ə keɪsmən ʌv ɡʊd ɡlæs peɪnz əɡɛns ðə koʊld, sæmɪtsu kəd si klɪɹli ðə wʊɾən skæfəldɪŋ ɪɹɛktəɾ ɝaʊn ðə ɹuən sɛkʃən ə ðə pæləs, bɹoʊkən kjubz ə dɑɹk stoʊn stɪl lɪɾɝd wɪð ɹʌbəl ən stɛp taʊɝz ðət stɑpt əbɹʌpli ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ikwəlɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæləsəz taʊɝz. wʌn, ðə taʊɝ ə ðə ɹɪzən sʌn, wɑz sɪmpli noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðɛɹ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə sɪɾiz feɪbəld "tɑpləs" taʊɝz lum θɹu ðə dʒɹɪftɪŋ waɪt fleɪks, ɪnɔɹməs skwɛɹ spaɪɹz wɪð hjudʒ bʌtʃɹəsəz, mʌtʃ tɔlɝ baɪ fɑɹ ðən ɛni ɪn ðə pæləs dɪspaɪɾ ɪts loʊkeɪʃən ɑn ðə haɪəs hɪl ɪn ə sɪɾi ʌv hɪlz. ðeɪ wɝ ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn skæfəlz ən stɪl nɑt kəmplitli ɹibɪl twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ði il hæd bɝn ðɛm; ənʌðɝ twɛnti maɪt si ðɛm dʌn.

Find him, and tell him I agree, but there will be a few more than we talked about." The light feathery snow falling on the city of Cairhien dimmed the morning sunlight only a little, just muting the brightness. From the tall narrow window in the Sun Palace, fitted with a casement of good glass panes against the cold, Samitsu could see clearly the wooden scaffolding erected around the ruined section of the palace, broken cubes of dark stone still littered with rubble and stepped towers that stopped abruptly short of equaling the rest of the palace's towers. One, the Tower of the Risen Sun, was simply no longer there. Several of the city's fabled "topless" towers loomed through the drifting white flakes, enormous square spires with huge buttresses, much taller by far than any in the palace despite its location on the highest hill in a city of hills. They were wrapped in their own scaffolds and still not completely rebuilt twenty years after the Aiel had burned them; another twenty might see them done.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɝkmɪn klæmbɝɪŋ; əlɔŋ ðə plæŋks ɑn ɛni ʌv ðə skæfəldɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑɾ ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ. ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ ðə snoʊ kəd ɡɪv əɹ ə ɹɛspɪt, tu.

There were no workmen clambering; along the planks on any of the scaffolding, of course, not in this weather. She found herself wishing the snow could give her a respite, too.

wən kædzueɪn dɪpɑɹɾəd ə wik pæst, livɪŋ əɹ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, hɝ tæsk hæɾ əpɪɹd stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə kɛɹhinɪn pɑt dɪd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə bɔɪl əɡɛn. ðət hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ə sɪmpəl tæsk ət ðə taɪm, ðoʊ ʃi hæd sɛldəm dæbəld ɪn pɑlətɪks tə spik ʌv oʊnli wʌn noʊbəl ɹɪteɪn saɪzəbəl fɔɹsɪz ʌndɝ ɑɹmz, ən dɑbɹeɪn wɑz koʊɑpɝeɪɾɪv, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, simɪŋ tə wɑn ɛvɹiθɪŋ kɛp kwaɪət. ʌv kɔɹs, hi hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðət ful əpɔɪnmənt əz 'stuɝɾ ə kɛɹhin fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." ðə bɔɪ hæd neɪmd ə "stuɝd" ʌv tɛɹ, tu, ə mæn u hæd bɪn ɪn ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ɪm ə mʌnθ ɡɔn! ɪf i hæd dʌn əz mʌtʃ ɪn ɪljən... ɪt simd ɔl tu pɹɑbəbəl. ðoʊz əpɔɪnmənts wəd kɑz noʊ ɛn ə tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ sɪstɝz tə sɔɹɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ɔl wɑz sɛɾ ən dʌn! ðə bɔɪ bɹɔt nʌθɪŋ bʌt tʃɹʌbəl!

When Cadsuane departed a week past, leaving her in charge, her task had appeared straightforward. Make sure the Cairhienin pot did not begin to boil again. That had appeared a simple task at the time, though she had seldom dabbled in politics to speak of only one noble retained sizable forces under arms, and Dobraine was cooperative, for the most part, seeming to want everything kept quiet. Of course, he had accepted that fool appointment as 'Steward of Cairhien for the Dragon Reborn." The boy had named a "Steward" of Tear, too, a man who had been in rebellion against him a month gone! If he had done as much in Illian... It seemed all too probable. Those appointments would cause no end of trouble for sisters to sort out before all was said and done! The boy brought nothing but trouble!

jɛt soʊ fɑɹ dɑbɹeɪn sim tə bi juzɪŋ ɪz nu poʊst oʊnli tə ɹʌn ðə sɪɾi. ən tə kwaɪətli ɹæli səpɔɹt fəɹ ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən ɛs kleɪm tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ meɪd wʌn. sæmɪtsu wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd tə liv ɪɾ ət ðæt, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ u tʊk ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ mʌtʃ fəɹ kɛɹhin əɾ ɔl.

Yet so far Dobraine seemed to be using his new post only to run the city. And to quietly rally support for Elayne Trakand s claim to the Sun Throne, if she ever made one. Samitsu was satisfied to leave it at that, not caring one way or another who took the Sun Throne. She did not care much for Cairhien at all.

ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ bɪɑn əɹ wɪndoʊ swɝld ɪn ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn laɪk ə waɪt kəlaɪɾəskoʊp. soʊ...

The falling snow beyond her window swirled in a gust of wind like a white kaleidoscope. So...

tʃɹæŋkwəl. hæd ʃi ɛvɝ væljud tʃɹæŋkwɪlɪɾi bɪfɔɹ? ʃi sɝɾənli kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ɪt, ɪf ʃi hæd.

tranquil. Had she ever valued tranquility before? She certainly could not recall it, if she had.

niðɝ ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən teɪkɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn nɔɹ dɑbɹeɪnz nu taɪɾəl hæd bɹɔt nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ kɑnstɝneɪʃən əz ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs, ən ɹədɪkjələsli pɝsɪstənt, ɹumɝz əbaʊt ði ælθɹ bɔɪ ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə səbmɪt tə ɪleɪɾə, ðoʊ ʃi hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə kwɛl ðoʊz. ðət teɪl hæɾ ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm noʊbəlz tə steɪbəlmən hæf əfɹeɪd tə bɹið wɪtʃ wɑz vɛɹi wɛl ən ɡʊd fəɹ meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðə pis. ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz hæd ɡɹaʊn tə ə hɔlt; wɛl, kəmpɛɹd tə haʊ mæɾɝz nɔɹməli wɝ ɪn kɛɹhin. ði il u keɪm ɪndə ðə sɪɾi fɹəm ðɛɹ hjudʒ kæmp ə fju maɪlz is vɛɹi laɪkli hɛlpt, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ wɝ heɪɾəd baɪ ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹʌn ə foʊk. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðeɪ fɑloʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə ɹɪsk faɪndɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn ðə ɹɔŋ ɛn ə θaʊzənz ʌv il spɪɹz.

Neither the possibility of Elayne Trakand taking the throne nor Dobraine's new title had brought nearly as much consternation as the ridiculous, and ridiculously persistent, rumors about the al'Thor boy going to Tar Valon to submit to Elaida, though she had done nothing to quell those. That tale had everyone from nobles to stablemen half afraid to breathe which was very well and good for maintaining the peace. The Game of Houses had ground to a halt; well, compared to how matters normally were in Cairhien. The Aiel who came into the city from their huge camp a few miles east very likely helped, however much they were hated by the general run of folk. Everyone knew they followed the Dragon Reborn, and no one wanted to risk finding themselves on the wrong end of thousands of Aiel spears.

jʌŋ ælθɹ wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ jusfəl æbsən ðən pɹɛzənt. ɹumɝz aʊɾ ə ðə wɛst ʌv il ɹeɪɾɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ-luɾɪŋ, bɝnɪŋ, kɪlɪŋ ɪndɪskɹɪmənətli, soʊ mɝtʃəns' hɪɹseɪ kleɪmd-ɡeɪv pipəl ənʌðɝ ɹizən tə stɛp dʒɪnʒɝli wɪð ðoʊz hɪɹ.

Young al'Thor was much more useful absent than present. Rumors out of the west of Aiel raiding elsewhere-looting, burning, killing indiscriminately, so merchants' hearsay claimed-gave people another reason to step gingerly with those here.

ɪn fækt, ðəɹ sim tə bi noʊ bɝz tə pɹɪk kɛɹhin aʊɾ ʌv ɪts kwaɪət, əsaɪd fɹəm ði əkeɪʒənəl stʃɹit bɹɔl bɪtwin fɔɹɡeɪɾɝz ən sɪɾi foʊk u kənsɪɾɝd ðə nɔɪzi, bɹaɪtli klæd fɔɹɡeɪɾɝz əz eɪliən əz ði il ən ə ɡʊd dil seɪfɝ tə faɪt. ðə sɪɾi wɑz kɹaʊɾəd tə ði æɾɪks, wɪð pipəl slipɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə koʊld, jɛt fud səplaɪz wɝ mɔɹ ðən æɾəkwət ɪf nɑɾ oʊvɝəbʌndənt, ən tʃɹeɪd wɑz æktʃəli  bɛɾɝ ðən ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn wɪntɝ-ɔl ɪn ɔl, ʃʊɾə əv fɛl kɑntɛn ðət ʃi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ aʊt kædzueɪnz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz əz wɛl əz ðə ɡɹin kəd wɪʃ fɔɹ. ɪksɛp ðət kædzueɪn wəɾ ɪkspɛk mɔɹ. ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd.

In fact, there seemed to be no burrs to prick Cairhien out of its quiet, aside from the occasional street brawl between Foregaters and city folk who considered the noisy, brightly clad Foregaters as alien as the Aiel and a good deal safer to fight. The city was crowded to the attics, with people sleeping anywhere they could find shelter from the cold, yet food supplies were more than adequate if not overabundant, and trade was actually better than expected in winter-All in all, she should have felt content that she was carrying out Cadsuane's instructions as well as the Green could wish for. Except that Cadsuane would expect more. She always did.

'ɑɹ jə lɪsnɪŋ tə mi, sæmɪtsu!"

'Are you listening to me, Samitsu!"

saɪɪŋ, sæmɪtsu tɝn fɹəm ðə pisfəl vju θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ, teɪkɪŋ peɪnz nɑt tə smuð əɹ jɛloʊ-slæʃt skɝts. ðə dʒɑkændə-meɪd sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ tɪŋkəl feɪnli, bʌt tədeɪ ðə saʊn feɪl tə suð hɝ. ət ðə bɛst ə taɪmz ʃi dɪd nɑt fil ɪntaɪɝli kʌmftəɹbəl ɪn əɹ əpɑɹtməns ɪn ðə pæləs, ðoʊ ə bleɪzɪŋ faɪɝ ɪn ðə waɪd mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd wɔɹmθ ən ðə bɛɾ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum hæd ðə bɛst-kwɑləɾi fɛðɝ mætʃɹəsəz ən ɡus-daʊn pɪloʊz. ɔl θɹi ʌv əɹ ɹumz wɝ oʊvɝli ɔɹneɪɾ ɪn ðə səvɪɹ kɛɹhinɪn fæʃən, ðə waɪt silɪŋ plæstɝ wɝkt ɪn ɪntɝlɑkɪŋ skwɛɹz, ðə waɪd bɑɹ-kɔɹnɪsəz hɛvəli ɡɪldɪd, ən ðə wʊɾən wɔl-pænəlz pɑlɪʃt tə ə sɑft ɡloʊ jɛt dɑɹk ivən soʊ. ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ dɑɹkɝ stɪl ən mæsɪvli kənstʃɹʌktəd, ɛdʒd wɪð θɪn laɪnz ʌv ɡoʊld lif ən ɪnleɪd wɪð pæɾɝnd aɪvɝi wɛdʒəz. ðə flaʊɝd tɛɹən kɑɹpəɾ ɪn ðɪs ɹum simd ɡɛɹɪʃli dɪsɔɹɾɝd kəmpɛɹd tə ɛvɹi θɪŋ ɛls, ən ɛmfəsaɪz ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ stɪfnəs. ɪɾ ɔl sim tu mʌtʃ laɪk ə keɪdʒ ə leɪt.

Sighing, Samitsu turned from the peaceful view through the window, taking pains not to smooth her yellow-slashed skirts. The Jakanda-made silver bells in her hair tinkled faintly, but today the sound failed to soothe her. At the best of times she did not feel entirely comfortable in her apartments in the palace, though a blazing fire in the wide marble fireplace gave a good warmth and the bed in the next room had the best-quality feather mattresses and goose-down pillows. All three of her rooms were overly ornate in the severe Cairhienin fashion, the white ceiling plaster worked in interlocking squares, the wide bar-cornices heavily gilded, and the wooden wall-panels polished to a soft glow yet dark even so. The furnishings were darker still and massively constructed, edged with thin lines of gold leaf and inlaid with patterned ivory wedges. The flowered Tairen carpet in this room seemed garishly disordered compared to every thing else, and emphasized the surrounding stiffness. It all seemed too much like a cage of late.

wʌt ɹɪli dəskɑmfəɾəd hɝ, ðoʊ, wɑz ðə wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ɹɪŋləts tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɑɹpət, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, ə bəlɪdʒɝən sɛt tə hɝ tʃɪn, ən ə fɹaʊn nɛɹoʊɪŋ əɹ blu aɪz. sæʃəl wɔɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hænd, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ ən il nɛkləs ən bɹeɪslət, fæt bidz ə sɪlvɝ ən aɪvɝi ɪntʃɹəkətli wɝkt ən kɑɹvd, ɡɔɾi əɡɛnst əɹ haɪ-nɛk dʒɹɛs ə bɹaʊn wʊl, wɪtʃ wɑz pleɪn ɪf faɪn ən wɛl-kʌt. nɑt kɹud pisəz, sɝɾənli, bʌt... flæmbɔɪənt, ən hɑɹdli ðə sɔɹɾ ə sɪstɝ wəd wɛɹ. ði ɑɾəti ʌv ðət dʒuəlɹi maɪt hoʊl ðə ki tə mʌtʃ, ɪf sæmɪtsu kəɾ ɛvɝ faɪn ðə ɹizən bɪhaɪn ɪt. ðə waɪz wʌnz, ɪspɛʃli sɔɹɪliə, lʊkt əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə ful fəɹ nɑt noʊɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ, ən ɹəfjuz tə bi bɑðɝd wɪð ænsɝɪŋ.

What really discomfited her, though, was the woman with her hair in ringlets to her shoulders standing in the middle of the carpet, fists on her hips, a belligerent set to her chin, and a frown narrowing her blue eyes. Sashalle wore the Great Serpent ring, of course, on her right hand, but also an Aiel necklace and bracelet, fat beads of silver and ivory intricately worked and carved, gaudy against her high-necked dress of brown wool, which was plain if fine and well-cut. Not crude pieces, certainly, but... flamboyant, and hardly the sort a sister would wear. The oddity of that jewelry might hold the key to much, if Samitsu could ever find the reason behind it. The Wise Ones, especially Sorilea, looked at her as if she were a fool for not knowing without asking, and refused to be bothered with answering.

ðeɪ dɪd ðəɾ ɔl tu ɔfən. moʊst ɪspɛʃli sɔɹɪliə. sæmɪtsu wɑz ənjuz tə biɪŋ θɔɾ ə ful, ən ʃi dɪslaɪkt ɪɾ ɪmɛnsli.

They did that all too often. Most especially Sorilea. Samitsu was unused to being thought a fool, and she disliked it immensely.

nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ʃi faʊn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə mit ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɡeɪz. sæʃəl wɑz ðə meɪdʒɝ ɹizən kəntɛnmənt ɪluɾɪd hɝ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ wɛl ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ʌðɝwaɪz. moʊs mæɾənɪŋ, sæʃəl wɑz ə ɹɛd, jɛt dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ədʒɑ, ʃi wɑz oʊθswɔɹn tə jʌŋ ælθɹ. haʊ kəɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ swɛɹ fiəlti tə ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl? meɪbi vɛɹɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt tɑvɝən twɪstɪŋ tʃæns. sæmɪtsu kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə θɪŋk ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ θɝɾi-wʌn sɪstɝz, faɪv, ʌv əm ɹɛd, tə teɪk sətʃ ən oʊθ.

Not for the first time, she found it difficult to meet the other sister's gaze. Sashalle was the major reason contentment eluded her, no matter how well everything was going otherwise. Most maddening, Sashalle was a Red, yet despite her Ajah, she was oathsworn to young al'Thor. How could any Aes Sedai swear fealty to a man who could channel? Maybe Verin had been right about ta'veren twisting chance. Samitsu could not begin to think of any other reason for thirty-one sisters, five, of them Red, to take such an oath.

"ðə leɪɾi eɪlɪl əz bɪn əpɹoʊtʃt baɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz u ɹɛpɹəzɛn moʊst ə haʊs ɹieɪɾənz stʃɹɛŋkθ" ʃi ɹɪplaɪd, mʌtʃ mɔɹ peɪʃənli ðən ʃi fɛlt. "ðeɪ wɑn əɹ tə teɪk ðə haɪ siɾ ə ɹieɪɾən, ən ʃi wɑns waɪt taʊɝ əpɹuvəl. ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɹuvəl, ət list." fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə də bɪsaɪdz mætʃ stɛɹz-æn laɪkli luz-ʃi muv tə ə blækwʊd teɪbəl wɛɹ ə ɡoʊld-wɝk sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ sɪɾɪŋ; ɑn ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ stɪl ɡeɪv ɔf ðə feɪn sɛn ə spaɪsəz. fɪlɪŋ ə kʌp wɪð mʌld waɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd ən ɪkskjus tə bɹeɪk ðə flɪɹɪŋ aɪ kɑntækt. niɾɪŋ ən ɪkskjus meɪɾ əɹ ɹipleɪs ðə pɪtʃɝ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp klɪŋk. ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf əvɔɪɾɪŋ lʊkɪŋ ət sæʃəl tu ɔfən. ivən naʊ, ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən saɪdweɪz. tə hɝ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ʃi kəd nɑt kwaɪt meɪk hɝsɛlf tɝn kəmplitli tə miɾ əɹ stɛɹ.

"The Lady Ailil has been approached by lords and ladies who represent most of House Riatin's strength" she replied, much more patiently than she felt. "They want her to take the High Seat of Riatin, and she wants White Tower approval. Aes Sedai approval, at least." For something to do besides match stares-and likely lose-she moved to a blackwood table where a gold-worked silver pitcher sitting; on a silver tray still gave off the faint scent of spices. Filling a cup with mulled wine provided an excuse to break the fleering eye contact. Needing an excuse made her replace the pitcher on the tray with a sharp clink. She found herself avoiding looking at Sashalle too often. Even now, she realized she was looking at the other woman sideways. To her frustration, she could not quite make herself turn completely to meet her stare.

'tɛl əɹ noʊ, sæʃəl. hɝ bɹʌðɝ wɑz stɪl əlaɪv wən læst sin, ən ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz nʌθɪŋ ðət nid kənsɝn ðə taʊɝ; sɝɾənli nɑt naʊ ɪts dʌn wɪð." ðə mɛmɹi ɝoʊz ə tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən əz læst sin, ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf ɪndə ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fɑɡ ðət kəd teɪk ɑn sɑləd fɔɹm ən kɪl, ə fɑɡ ðət ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðə ʃædoʊ hæd wɔkt aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz ə kɛɹhin ðət deɪ.

'Tell her no, Sashalle. Her brother was still alive when last seen, and rebellion against the Dragon Reborn is nothing that need concern the Tower; certainly not now it's done with." The memory arose of Toram Riatin as last seen, running off into a strange fog that could take on solid form and kill, a fog that resisted the One Power. The Shadow had walked outside the walls of Cairhien that day.

sæmɪtsuz vɔɪs taɪɾənd fɹəm ði ɛfɝt tə stɑp ɪt ʃɔɹɾ ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. nɑt wɪð fɪɹ, bʌɾ æŋɡɝ. ðət hæd bɪn ðə deɪ ʃi feɪld ət hilɪŋ jʌŋ ælθɹ. ʃi heɪɾəd feɪljɝz, heɪɾəd ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðɛm. ən ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv tə ɪkspleɪn hɝsɛlf. "moʊst ə ɹieɪɾənz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪz noʊ tɔl. ðoʊz stɪl taɪd tə tɔɹæm wɪl əpoʊz hɝ, wɪð fɔɹs ʌv ɑɹmz ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, ən ɪn ɛni keɪs, fɑstɝɪŋ əphivəl ɪnsaɪd ðə haʊsəz ðɛmsɛlvz ɪz noʊ weɪ tə meɪnteɪn ðə pis. ðəɹ ɪz ə pɹikɛɹiəs bæləns ɪn kɛɹhin naʊ, sæʃəl, bʌɾ ɪts ə bæləns, ən wi mʌsnt dɪstɝb ɪt." ʃi mænədʒ tə stɑp ʃɔɹɾ ə seɪɪŋ kædzueɪn wəd bi dɪsplizd ɪf ðeɪ dɪd. ðət wəd hɑɹdli kæɹi weɪt wɪð sæʃəl.

Samitsu's voice tightened from the effort to stop it short of trembling. Not with fear, but anger. That had been the day she failed at Healing young al'Thor. She hated failures, hated remembering them. And she should not have to explain herself. "Most of Riatin's strength is no tall. Those still tied to Toram will oppose her, with force of arms if necessary, and in any case, fostering upheaval inside the Houses themselves is no way to maintain the peace. There is a precarious balance in Cairhien now, Sashalle, but it is a balance, and we mustn't disturb it." She managed to stop short of saying Cadsuane would be displeased if they did. That would hardly carry weight with Sashalle.

"əphivəl wɪl kʌm wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt wi fɑstɝ ɪt," ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ sɛd fɝmli. hɝ fɹaʊn hæd feɪɾəd əz sun əz sæmɪtsu ʃoʊd ʃi hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ, ðoʊ ðə sɛɾ ə hɝ dʒɔ ɹɪmeɪnd. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz stʌbɝnnəs ɹæðɝ ðən bəlɪdʒɝəns, jɛt ðət hɑɹdli mæɾɝd. ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɝ, dʒʌst steɪɾɪŋ əɹ oʊn pəzɪʃən. ən moʊst ɡɔlɪŋ ʌv ɔl, pleɪnli duɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ əz ə kɝɾəsi. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz ðə hɛɹəld ʌv əphivəl ən tʃeɪnʒ, sæmɪtsu. ðə hɛɹəl fɔɹtoʊld.

"Upheaval will come whether or not we foster it," the other sister said firmly. Her frown had faded as soon as Samitsu showed she had been listening, though the set of her jaw remained. Perhaps it was stubbornness rather than belligerence, yet that hardly mattered. The woman was not arguing or trying to convince her, just stating her own position. And most galling of all, plainly doing that much as a courtesy. "The Dragon Reborn is the herald of upheaval and change, Samitsu. The herald foretold.

ən ɪf i wɝnt, ðɪs ɪz kɛɹhin. dʒju θɪŋk ðeɪv ɹɪli stɑpt pleɪɪŋ ət deɪz deɪmɑɹ? ðə sɝfəs ə ðə wɔɾɝ meɪ bi stɪl, bʌt ðə fɪʃ nɛvɝ stɑp swɪmɪŋ." eɪ ɹɛd pɹitʃɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn laɪk ə stʃɹit kɔɹnɝ dɛməɡɑɡ! laɪt! "æn ɪf jə ɑɹ ɹɔŋ:" ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, sæmɪtsu bɪɾ ɔf ðə wɝdz. sæʃəl-bɝn hɝ! -meɪnteɪn ə pɝfək sɝɛnəɾi.

And if he weren't, this is Cairhien. Do you think they have really stopped playing at Daes Dae'mar? The surface of the water may be still, but the fish never stop swimming." A Red preaching the Dragon Reborn like a street corner demagogue! Light! "And if you are wrong:" In spite of herself, Samitsu bit off the words. Sashalle-burn her! -maintained a perfect serenity.

"eɪlɪl əz fɔɹswɔɹn ɛni kleɪm tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd wɪtʃ ɪz wʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn dɪzaɪɝz, ən ʃiz ɹɛɾi tə swɛɹ fiəlti tə hɪm, ɪf aɪ æsk ɪt. tɔɹæm lɛɾ ən ɑɹmi əɡɛnst ɹænd ælθɹ. aɪ seɪ ðə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz wɝθ meɪkɪŋ ən ðə tʃæns wɝθ teɪkɪŋ, ən əl tɛl əɹ soʊ." ðə bɛlz ɪn sæmɪtsuz hɛɹ tʃaɪmd əɾ ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ən ʃi bɛɹli mænədʒ tə stɑp hɝsɛlf fɹəm saɪɪŋ əɡɛn. eɪtin ə ðoʊz dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn sɪstɝz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kɛɹhin. kædzueɪn hæd kæɹid səm əweɪ wɪð hɝ, ðən sɛn ɑlɑnə bæk tə teɪkɔf stɪl mɔɹ-æn ʌðɝz ə ði eɪtin bɪsaɪdz sæʃəl stʊd haɪɝ ðən ʃi, bʌt ði il waɪz wʌnz kɛpt əm aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ. ɪn pɹɪnsəpəl, ʃi dɪsəpɹuvd ə haʊ ðət wɑz dʌn-ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt bi əpɹɛntəsɪz, nɑt tə ɛniwʌn! ɪt wɑz aʊtʃɹeɪdʒəs! -bʌɾ ɪn pɹæktəs, ɪt dɪd meɪk əɹ dʒɑb iziɝ. ðeɪ kəd nɑt mɛɾəl əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ wɪð waɪz wʌnz ɹʌnɪŋ ðɛɹ laɪvz ən wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɛvɹi aʊɝ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃi kəd nɑt lɝn, ðə waɪz wʌnz lʊk dɪfɹənli ɑn sæʃəl ən ði ʌðɝ tu sɪstɝz u hæd bɪn seɪld ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. stɪld. ʃi fɛlt ə feɪnt ʃɪvɝ ət ðə θɔt, bʌɾ oʊnli feɪnt! ən ɪt wəd bi lɛs ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ mænədʒ tə wɝk aʊt haʊ deɪmɝ flɪn hæd hild wʌt kəd nɑt bi hild. ət list sʌmwʌn kəd hil stɪlɪŋ, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz ə mæn. ə mæn tʃænəlɪŋ. laɪt, haʊ ðə hɔɹɝ ə jɛstɝdeɪ bɪkeɪm mɪɹli ði ʌnizinəs ə tədeɪ, wʌns jə ɡɹu əkʌstəmd.

"Ailil has forsworn any claim to the Sun Throne in favor of Elayne Trakand which is what the Dragon Reborn desires, and she is ready to swear fealty to him, if I ask it. Toram led an army against Rand al'Thor. I say the change is worth making and the chance worth taking, and I will tell her so." The bells in Samitsu's hair chimed at an irritated shake of her head, and she barely managed to stop herself from sighing again. Eighteen of those Dragonsworn sisters remained in Cairhien. Cadsuane had carried some away with her, then sent Alanna back to takeoff still more-and others of the eighteen besides Sashalle stood higher than she, but the Aiel Wise Ones kept them out of her way. In principle, she disapproved of how that was done-Aes Sedai could not be apprentices, not to anyone! It was outrageous! -but in practice, it did make her job easier. They could not meddle or try to take charge with Wise Ones running their lives and watching over their every hour. Unfortunately for some reason she could not learn, the Wise Ones Looked differently on Sashalle and the other two sisters who had been sailed at Dumai's Wells. Stilled. She felt a faint shiver at the thought, but only faint! and it would be less if she ever managed to work out how Damer Flinn had Healed what could not be Healed. At least someone could Heal stilling, even if it was a man. A man channeling. Light, how the horror of yesterday became merely the uneasiness of today, once you grew accustomed.

ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət kædzueɪn wʊɾə ɝeɪnʒd mæɾɝz wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ hæd ʃi noʊn əbaʊt ðə dɪfɝəns wɪð sæʃəl ən ɝɡən ən ɹɑneɪl. ət list, ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi hæd bɪn pʊld ɪndə wʌn ə ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɡɹinz dɪzaɪnz.

She was sure that Cadsuane would have arranged matters with the Wise Ones before leaving had she known about the difference with Sashalle and Irgain and Ronaille. At least, she thought she was sure. This was not the first time she had been pulled into one of the legendary Green's designs.

kædzueɪn kəd bi mɔɹ diviəs ðən ə blu, skimz ɪnsaɪd plɑts ɹæpt ɪn stʃɹæɾədʒəmz ən ɔl hɪɾən bɪhaɪn stɪl ʌðɝz. səm wɝ plæn tə feɪl ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə hɛlp ʌðɝz səksid, ən oʊnli kædzueɪn nu wɪtʃ wɝ wɪtʃ, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ θɔt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðoʊz θɹi sɪstɝz wɝ fɹi tə kʌm ən ɡoʊ, əz ðeɪ dɪzaɪɝd, də əz ðeɪ dɪzaɪɝd. ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli fɛl noʊ nid tə fɑloʊ ðə ɡaɪɾəns kædzueɪn hæd lɛf bɪhaɪn əɹ tə fɑloʊ ðə sɪstɝ ʃi hæd neɪm tə lid. oʊnli ðɛɹ mæɾ oʊθ tə ælθɹ ɡaɪɾəd əɹ kənstʃɹeɪn ðɛm.

Cadsuane could be more devious than a Blue, schemes inside plots wrapped in stratagems and all hidden behind still others. Some were planned to fail in order to help others succeed, and only Cadsuane knew which were which, not at all a comforting thought. In any case, those three sisters were free to come and go, as they desired, do as they desired. And they certainly felt no need to follow the guidance Cadsuane had left behind or to follow the sister she had named to lead. Only their mad oath to al'Thor guided or constrained them.

sæmɪtsu hæd nɛvɝ fɛlt wik əɹ ɪnəfɛktʃuəl ɪn əɹ laɪf ɪksɛpt wən əɹ tælən feɪl hɝ, jɛt ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɪʃt ðət kædzueɪn wəd ɹɪtɝn ən teɪk mæɾɝz aʊɾ ə hɝ hænz. ə fju wɝdz dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪn eɪlɪlz ɪɹ wəd kwɛntʃ ɛni dɪzaɪɝ ðə leɪɾi bæd tə maʊn ðə haɪ sit, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛɾ ɪt wəd kʌm tə nʌθɪŋ ənlɛs ʃi faʊn səm weɪ tə dɪflɛk sæʃəl fɹəm əɹ pɝpəs. noʊ mæɾɝ ðəɾ eɪlɪl fɪɹd hævɪŋ əɹ sɪli sikɹəts ɛɹɾ əbɹɔd, ɪnkənsɪstənsi ɪn wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ toʊld əɹ kəd wɛl meɪk əɹ dɪsaɪɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ tə tʃɹaɪ vænɪʃɪŋ tə hɝ kʌntʃɹi ɪsteɪts ɹæðɝ ðən ɹɪsk əfɛndɪŋ ə sɪstɝ wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd. kædzueɪn wəd bi əpsɛɾ oʊvɝ luzɪŋ eɪlɪl. sæmɪtsu hɝsɛlf wəd bi ʌpsɛt. eɪlɪl wɑz ə kɑnduɪɾ ɪndə hæf ðə plɑts bɹuɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə noʊbəlz, ə ɡeɪdʒ tə bi ʃʊɹ ðoʊz ɪntʃɹiɡz wɝ ɔl stɪl pɛɾi ən ənlaɪkli tə bɹɪŋ ɛni meɪdʒɝ dɪstɝbəns. ðə kɝst ɹɛd nu ðæt. ən wʌns sæʃəl ɡeɪv eɪlɪl ðɪs pɝmɪʃən, ɪt wəd bi hɝ ðə wʊmən keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə wɪð əɹ nuz, nɑt sæmɪtsu tɑmɑɡoʊə.

Samitsu had never felt weak or ineffectual in her life except when her Talent failed her, yet she very much wished that Cadsuane would return and take matters out of her hands. A few words delivered in Ailil's ear would quench any desire the lady bad to mount the High Seat, of course, yet it would come to nothing unless she found some way to deflect Sashalle from her purpose. No matter that Ailil feared having her silly secrets aired abroad, inconsistency in what Aes Sedai told her could well make her decide it was better to try vanishing to her country estates rather than risk offending a sister whatever she did. Cadsuane would be upset over losing Ailil. Samitsu herself would be upset. Ailil was a conduit into half the plots brewing among the nobles, a gauge to be sure those intrigues were all still petty and unlikely to bring any major disturbance. The cursed Red knew that. And once Sashalle gave Ailil this permission, it would be her the woman came running to with her news, not Samitsu Tamagowa.

waɪl sæmɪtsu wɑz flaʊndɝɪŋ ɪn əɹ kwɑndɝi, ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔlweɪ oʊpən tə ədmɪɾ ə peɪl, stɝn-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən iðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz ɪn ə θɪk ɡɹeɪ ɹoʊl ɑn ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk, ən ʃi wɔɹ ən ʌnədɔɹnd ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs soʊ dɑɹk ɪt wɑz nɪɹli blæk, ðə kɝən lɪvɝi ʌv ə sʌn pæləs sɝvənt. sɝvəns nɛvɝ ənaʊns ðɛmsɛlvz əɹ æskt ədmɪɾəns, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt kɔɹɡeɪd mɑɹɛndɪvɪn wɑz hɑɹdli dʒʌst ənʌðɝ sɝvənt; ðə hɛvi sɪlvɝi ɹɪŋ ə lɔŋ kiz əɾ əɹ weɪst wɑz ə bædʒ ʌv ɔfəs. huɛvɝ ɹul kɛɹhin, ðə hoʊldɝ ə ðə kiz ɹul ðə sʌn pæləs ɪn sɪmpəl fækt, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ səbmɪsɪv ɪn kɔɹɡeɪdz mænɝ. ʃi meɪɾ ə mɪnəməl kɝtsi kɛɹfəli eɪm hæfweɪ bɪtwin sæmɪtsu ən sæʃəl.

While Samitsu was floundering in her quandary, the door to the hallway opened to admit a pale, stern-faced Cairhienin woman, a hand shorter than either Aes Sedai. Her hair was in a thick gray roll on the nape of her neck, and she wore an unadorned gray dress so dark it was nearly black, the current livery of a Sun Palace servant. Servants never announced themselves or asked admittance, of course, but Corgaide Marendevin was hardly just another servant; the heavy silvery ring of long keys at her waist was a badge of office. Whoever ruled Cairhien, the Holder of the Keys ruled the Sun Palace in simple fact, and there was nothing submissive in Corgaide's manner. She made a minimal curtsy carefully aimed halfway between Samitsu and Sashalle.

"aɪ wɑz æsk tə ɹipɔɹɾ ɛniθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl," ʃi sɛd tə ði ɛɹ, ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn sæmɪtsu hu æskt-vɛɹi laɪkli, ʃi hæd noʊn ə ðə paʊɝ stʃɹʌɡəl bɪtwin əm əz sun əz ðeɪ dɪd ðɛmsɛlvz.

"I was asked to report anything unusual," she said to the air, though it had been Samitsu who asked-Very likely, she had known of the power struggle between them as soon as they did themselves.

lɪɾəl ɪn ðə pæləs ɪskeɪp hɝ. "aɪ æm koʊl ðəɹ ɪz ən oʊɡiɝ ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz. hi ən ə jʌŋ mæn səpoʊzədli ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ æftɝ wɝk, əz meɪsənz, bʌɾ aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv oʊɡiɝ ən hjumən meɪsənz wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ən stɛɾɪŋ tsəfu sɛnt wɝd noʊ meɪsənz wəd bi əveɪləbəl fɹəm ɛni stɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɔɹsiəbəl fjutʃɝ, wən wi ɪnkwaɪɝɾ æftɝ . . . ði ɪnsəɾənt." ðə pɔz wɑz bɛɹli pɝsɛptəbəl, ən əɹ ɡɹeɪv ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ, bʌt hɔl ðə ɡɑsəp əbaʊt ði ətæk ɑn ðə sʌn pæləs leɪɾ ɪt tə ælθɹz duɪŋ, ði ʌðɝ hæf tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə fju teɪlz mɛnʃən ðə fɔɹseɪkən, bʌɾ oʊnli tə pɛɹ əm wɪð iðɝ ælθɹ əɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Little in the palace escaped her. "I am cold there is an Ogier in the kitchens. He and a young man supposedly are looking after work, as masons, but I have never heard of Ogier and human masons working together. And Stedding Tsofu sent word no masons would be available from any stedding for the foreseeable future, when we inquired after . . . the incident." The pause was barely perceptible, and her grave expression did not alter, but hall the gossip about the attack on the Sun Palace laid it to al'Thor's doing, the other half to Aes Sedai. A few tales mentioned the Forsaken, but only to pair them with either al'Thor or the Aes Sedai.

pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps ɪn θɔt, sæmɪtsu sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə kɝs tæŋɡəl kɛɹhinɪn meɪɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ tʌtʃt. dɪnaɪəlz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnvɑlvmənt: dɪd lɪɾəl ɡʊd; ðə θɹi oʊðz oʊnli wɛn soʊ fɑɹ ɪn ə sɪɾi wɛɹ ə sɪmpəl jɛs əɹ noʊ kəd ɡɪv ɹaɪz tə sɪks kɑntʃɹədɪktɝi ɹumɝz. bʌt, oʊɡiɝ . . . ðə pæləs kɪtʃənz skɛɹsli tʊk ɪn stʃɹeɪ pæsɝzbi, jɛt ðə kʊks vɛɹi laɪkli wəd ɡɪv ən oʊɡiɝ ə hɑt mil dʒʌs fəɹ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə siɪŋ hɪm. oʊɡiɝ wɝ ivən mɔɹ ənkɑmən ðən juʒəwəl, ðɪs læs jɪɹ əɹ soʊ. ə fju wɝ stɪl sin naʊ ən ðɛn, bʌt wɔkɪŋ əz fæst əz oʊnli ən oʊɡiɝ kʊd, ən sɛldəm stɑpɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs mɔɹ ðən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə slip. ðeɪ ɹɛɹli tʃɹævəld wɪð hjumənz, haʊɛvɝ, mʌtʃ lɛs wɝkt wɪð ðɛm. ðə pɛɹɪŋ tɪkəl sʌmθɪŋ ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ðoʊ. hoʊpɪŋ tə tiz wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ɪndə ði oʊpən, ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə æsk ə fju kwɛstʃənz.

Pursing her lips in thought, Samitsu set aside the cursed tangle Cairhienin made of everything they touched. Denials of Aes Sedai involvement: did little good; the Three Oaths only went so far in a city where a simple yes or no could give rise to six contradictory rumors. But, Ogier . . . The palace kitchens scarcely took in stray passersby, yet the cooks very likely would give an Ogier a hot meal just for the strangeness of seeing him. Ogier were even more uncommon than usual, this last year or so. A few were still seen now and then, but walking as fast as only an Ogier could, and seldom stopping in one place more than long enough to sleep. They rarely traveled with humans, however, much less worked with them. The pairing tickled something in her mind, though. Hoping to tease whatever it was into the open, she opened her mouth to ask a few questions.

'θæŋk ju, kɔɹɡeɪd," sæʃəl sɛd wɪð ə smaɪl. "juv bɪn moʊs hɛlpfəl. bʌɾ ɪf jəl liv ʌs, naʊ?" biɪŋ əbɹʌpt wɪð ðə hoʊldɝ ə ðə kiz wɑz ə ɡʊd weɪ tə faɪn jɝsɛlf wɪð dɝɾi bɛd-lɪnənz ən pʊɹli spaɪs milz, ʌn ɛmptid tʃeɪmbɝpəts ən mɛsədʒəz ðət wɛn əstʃɹeɪ, ə θaʊzən ənɔɪənsɪz ðət kəd meɪk faɪɝ ə mɪzɝi ən liv jə weɪɾɪŋ ɪn mʌd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əkɑmplɪʃ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl, jɛt sʌmhaʊ ðət smaɪl əpɪɹd tə teɪk ðə stɪŋ aʊɾ oʊ hɝ wɝdz fəɹ kɔɹɡeɪd. ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli ɪn əsɛn ən əɡɛn meɪd ðə smɔləs pɑsəbəl kɝtsi. ðɪs taɪm, ɑbviəsli tə sæʃəl.

'Thank you, Corgaide," Sashalle said with a smile. "You've been most helpful. But if you will leave us, now?" Being abrupt with the Holder of the Keys was a good way to find yourself with dirty bed-linens and poorly spiced meals, un emptied chamberpots and messages that went astray, a thousand annoyances that could make fire a misery and leave you wading in mud trying to accomplish anything at all, yet somehow that smile appeared to take the sting out o her words for Corgaide. The gray-haired woman bowed her head slightly in assent and again made the smallest possible curtsy. This time, obviously to Sashalle.

noʊ sunɝ hæd ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ðən sæmɪtsu θʌmpt əɹ sɪlvɝ kʌp bæk ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə splæʃ wɔɹm waɪn oʊvɝ əɹ ɹɪst ən ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ. ʃi wɑz ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ʌv eɪlɪl, ən naʊ ðə sʌn pæləs ɪtsɛlf əpɪɹd tə bi slɪpɪŋ θɹu hɝ fɪŋɡɝz! ɪt wɑz əz laɪkli kɔɹɡeɪd wəd spɹaʊt wɪŋz ən flaɪ əz kip saɪlən əbaʊt wʌt ʃi hæd sin hɪɹ, ən wʌtɛvɝ ʃi sɛd wəd flæʃ θɹu ðə pæləs ən ɪnfɛkt ɛvɹi sɝvən daʊn tə ðə mɛn u mʌkt aʊt ðə steɪbəlz-ðæt faɪnəl kɝtsi hæd meɪɾ ɪt kwaɪt klɪɹ wʌt ʃi θɔt. laɪt, bʌt sæmɪtsu heɪɾəd kɛɹhin! ðə kʌstəmz ə səvɪləɾi bɪtwin sɪstɝz wɝ dipli ɪnɡɹeɪnd, bʌt sæʃəl dɪd nɑt stæn haɪ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ hoʊld əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ðə feɪs ə ðɪs dɪzæstɝ, ən ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə dɪlɪvɝ ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ʌv ɪt.

No sooner had the door closed behind the gray-haired woman than Samitsu thumped her silver cup back on the tray hard enough to splash warm wine over her wrist and rounded on the Red sister. She was on the brink of losing control of Ailil, and now the Sun Palace itself appeared to be slipping through her fingers! It was as likely Corgaide would sprout wings and fly as keep silent about what she had seen here, and whatever she said would flash through the palace and infect every servant down to the men who mucked out the stables-That final curtsy had made it quite clear what she thought. Light, but Samitsu hated Cairhien! The customs of civility between sisters were deeply ingrained, but Sashalle did not stand high enough to make her hold her tongue in the face of this disaster, and she intended to deliver the rough side of it.

fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, ðoʊ, ʃi sɔ sæʃəlz feɪs-ɹɪli sɔ ɪt, pɝhæps fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm-æn sʌɾənli ʃi nu waɪ ɪt tʃɹʌbəld əɹ soʊ, pɝhæps ivən waɪ ʃi hæd faʊn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə lʊk dɝɛkli ət ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ. ɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs, aʊtsaɪɾ ə taɪm ən stændɪŋ əpɑɹt fɹəm eɪdʒ. moʊs pipəl wɝ ənʃʊɹ ə ðə lʊk əntɪl ɪt wɑz pɔɪntəɾ aʊt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ʌnmɪsteɪkəbəl tə ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ. pɝhæps səm bɪts ɹɪmeɪnd, skɹæps ðət meɪd sæʃəl əpɪɹ kloʊsɝ tə bjuɾəfəl ðən ʃi ɹɪli wɑz, vɛɾ ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl wəd pʊɾ ən eɪdʒ tə hɝ, sʌmwɛɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ðə ɹiləzeɪʃən fɹoʊz sæmɪtsuz tʌŋ.

Frowning at the other woman, though, she saw Sashalle's face-really saw it, perhaps for the first time-and suddenly she knew why it troubled her so, perhaps even why she had found it difficult to look directly at the Red sister. It was no longer an Aes Sedai face, outside of time and standing apart from age. Most people were unsure of the look until it was pointed out, but it was unmistakable to another sister. Perhaps some bits remained, scraps that made Sashalle appear closer to beautiful than she really was, vet anyone at all would put an age to her, somewhere short of her middle years. The realization froze Samitsu's tongue.

wʌt wɑz noʊn əbaʊt wɪmən u hæd bɪn stɪld wɑz lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ɹumɝ. ðeɪ ɹæn əweɪ ən hɪd fɹəm ʌðɝ sɪstɝz; ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðeɪ daɪd. juʒəwəli, ðeɪ daɪd sun ɹæðɝ ðən leɪt. ðə lɔs ə seɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən moʊst wɪmən kəd bɛɹ fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹɪli tɪɾəl-tætəl; əz fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, noʊ wʌn ɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm hæd hæd ðə nɝv tə tʃɹaɪ lɝnɪŋ mɔɹ. ðə ɹɛɹli æknɑlɪdʒ fɪɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹkəs kɔɹnɝ ʌv ɛvɹi sɪstɝz hɛd, ðət ðə seɪm feɪt maɪt kʌm tə hɝ wʌn deɪ ɪn ə kɛɹləs moʊmənt, kɛpt ɛniwʌn fɹəm wɑntɪŋ tə noʊ tu mʌtʃ. ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd haɪd ðɛɹ aɪz wən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə si. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ðoʊz ɹumɝz, ðoʊ, ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ən soʊ veɪɡ jə kəd nɛvɝ ɹikɔl wɛɹ jə hɝɾ əm fɝst, wɪspɝz ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪɹɪŋ, jɛt fɝɛvɝ floʊɾɪŋ əbaʊt. wʌn ðət sæmɪtsu hæɾ oʊnli hæf ɹɪmɛmbɝd; tɪl naʊ, sɛd ðəɾ ə wʊmən u wɑz stɪld ɡɹu jʌŋ əɡɛn, ɪf ʃi lɪvd. ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz sim luɾəkɹəs, tɪl naʊ. ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl hæd nɑt ɡɪvən sæʃəl bæk ɛvɹiθɪŋ. wʌns mɔɹ ʃi wəɾ əv tə wɝk wɪð ðə paʊɝ fəɹ jɪɹz tə ɡeɪn ðə feɪs ðət wəd pɹoʊkleɪm əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ɛni sɪstɝ u kəd si hɝ klɪɹli. əɹ . . . wəd ʃi ɹɪɡeɪn ɪt. ɪt simd ɪnɛvəɾəbəl, jɛt ðɪs wɑz ənmæp tɝeɪn. ən ɪf əɹ feɪs wɑz tʃeɪnʒd, wɑz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əbaʊɾ əɹ tʃeɪnʒd əz wɛl: sæmɪtsu ʃɪvɝd, hɑɹɾɝ ðən ʃi hæd fəɹ ðə θɔɾ ə stɪlɪŋ. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz əz wɛl ʃi hæd ɡɔn sloʊ ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl aʊt dɑɹnɝz weɪ ʌv hilɪŋ.

What was known about women who had been stilled was little better than rumor. They ran away and hid from other sisters; eventually, they died. Usually, they died soon rather than late. The loss of saidar was more than most women could bear for very long. But it was all really tittle-tattle; as far as she knew, no one in a very long time had had the nerve to try learning more. The rarely acknowledged fear in the darkest corner of every sister's head, that the same fate might come to her one day in a careless moment, kept anyone from wanting to know too much. Even Aes Sedai could hide their eyes when they did not want to see. There were always those rumors, though, almost never mentioned and so vague you could never recall where you heard them first, whispers on the edge of hearing, yet forever floating about. One that Samitsu had only half remembered; till now, said that a woman who was stilled grew young again, if she lived. It had always seemed ludicrous, till now. Regaining the ability to channel had not given Sashalle back everything. Once more she would have to work with the Power for years to gain the face that would proclaim her Aes Sedai to any sister who could see her clearly. Or . . . would she regain it. It seemed inevitable, yet this was unmapped terrain. And if her face was changed, was anything else about her changed as well: Samitsu shivered, harder than she had for the thought of stilling. Perhaps it was as well she had gone slow in trying to puzzle out Darner's way of Healing.

fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ il nɛkləs, sæʃəl simd ʌnəwɛɹ ðət sæmɪtsu hæɾ ɛni ɡɹivəns oʊvɝ əɹ bɪheɪvjɝ, ʌnəwɛɹ ə sæmɪtsu ɛs skɹuɾəni-"ðɪs meɪbi nʌθɪŋ, əɹ ɪt meɪ wɔɹən lʊkɪŋ ɪntu," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt kɔɹɡeɪd wɑz oʊnli ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ wʌt ʃi hɝd. ɪf wi wɑnə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ, wi mʌst ɡoʊ ən si fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz." wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts ən stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ ə ði əpɑɹtməns, livɪŋ sæmɪtsu oʊnli ə tʃɔɪs bɪtwin fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ɪt wɑz ɪntɑlɝəbəl! jɛt ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl.

Fingering her Aiel necklace, Sashalle seemed unaware that Samitsu had any grievance over her behavior, unaware of Samitsu s scrutiny-"This maybe nothing, or it may warrant looking into," she said, "but Corgaide was only reporting what she heard. If we want to learn anything, we must go and see for ourselves." Without another word, she gathered her skirts and started out of the apartments, leaving Samitsu only a choice between following or remaining behind. It was intolerable! Yet remaining was unthinkable.

sæʃəl wɑz noʊ tɔlɝ ðən ʃi, nɑt tə spik ʌv, bʌt ʃi hæd tə hɝi tə kip ʌp əz ðə ɹɛd ɡlaɪɾɪd swɪfli əlɔŋ waɪd, skwɛɹ-vɔltəd kɔɹɪɾɝz. teɪkɪŋ ðə lɛd wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən, ənlɛs ʃi tʃoʊz tə ɹʌn. ʃi fjumd ɪn saɪləns, ðoʊ ɪt ɹikwaɪɝd ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ. ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ ɪn pʌblɪk wɑz ɪmpɹɑpɝ ət bɛst. wɝs, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt, ɪt wəd bi fjuɾəl. ən ðət wəɾ oʊnli dɪɡ ðə hoʊl ʃi wɑz ɪn dipɝ. ʃi fɛlt ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dɪzaɪɝ tə kɪk sʌmθɪŋ.

Sashalle was no taller than she, not to speak of, but she had to hurry to keep up as the Red glided swiftly along wide, square-vaulted corridors. Taking the lead was out of the question, unless she chose to run. She fumed in silence, though it required gritting her teeth. Arguing with another sister in public was improper at best. Worse, without any doubt, it would be futile. And that would only dig the hole she was in deeper. She felt a very great desire to kick something.

stændlæmps ət ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪntɝvəlz ɡeɪv plɛnti ʌv laɪɾ ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹkəst stʃɹɛtʃəz ə hɔlweɪ bʌt ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl kʌlɝ əɹ dɛkɝeɪʃən bɪɑn ði əkeɪʒənəl tæpəstʃɹi wɪð ɛvɹi-θɪŋ ɪn ɪɾ ɝeɪnʒd ɪn ɔɹɾɝli fæʃən, wɛðɝ ænəməlz biɪŋ hʌntəɾ əɹ noʊbəlz faɪɾɪŋ ɡæənli ɪn bæɾəl. ə fju nɪtʃɪz ɪn ðə wɔlz hɛld ɔɹnəməns ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ si foʊk pɔɹsələn, ən ɪn səm kɔɹɪɾɝz ðə kɔɹnɪsəz wɝ wɝkt ɪn fɹizɪz, moʊs lɛft ənpeɪntɪd. ðət wɑz ɔl. kɛɹhinɪn hɪd ðɛɹ ɑpjələns aʊɾ ə pʌblɪk vju; əz ðeɪ dɪd wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ. ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən u hɝiɾ ɪndʌstʃɹiəsli əlɔŋ ðə hɔlz laɪk stʃɹimz ʌv æns wɔɹ lɪvɝi ðə kʌlɝ ə tʃɑɹkoʊl, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz ɪn sɝvəs tə noʊbəlz ɹɛzəɾənt ɪn ðə pæləs, hu sim bɹaɪt bɪsaɪd ðə ɹɛst, wɪð ðɛɹ haʊs bædʒɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðɛɹ bɹɛsts, ən ðɛɹ kɑlɝz ən səmtaɪmz slivz mɑɹkt ɪn haʊs kʌlɝz. wʌn əɹ tu ivən hæɾ ə koʊɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs ɔl ɪn haʊs kʌlɝz, ən əpɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊst ən aʊtləndɝ əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝz. bʌt ðeɪ ɔl kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz daʊn ən bɛɹli pɔz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɔfɝ kwɪk baʊz əɹ kɝtsiz tə ðə tu sɪstɝz əz ðeɪ pæst. ðə sʌn pæləs ɹikwaɪɝd kaʊnləs hʌnʒɹədz ə sɝvəns, ən ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ ɔl skɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ tɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɔɹz.

Standlamps at regular intervals gave plenty of light even in the darkest stretches of hallway but there was little color or decoration beyond the occasional tapestry with every-thing in it arranged in orderly fashion, whether animals being hunted or nobles fighting gallantly in battle. A few niches in the walls held ornaments of gold or Sea Folk porcelain, and in some corridors the cornices were worked in friezes, most left unpainted. That was all. Cairhienin hid their opulence out of public view; as they did with so much. The serving men and women who hurried industriously along the halls like streams of ants wore livery the color of charcoal, except for those in service to nobles resident in the palace, who seemed bright beside the rest, with their House badges embroidered on their breasts, and their collars and sometimes sleeves marked in House colors. One or two even had a coat or dress all in House colors, and appeared almost an outlander among the others. But they all kept their eyes down and barely paused long enough to offer quick bows or curtsies to the two sisters as they passed. The Sun Palace required countless hundreds of servants, and it seemed they were all scurrying about this morning tending their chores.

noʊbəlz stʃɹoʊl ðə hɔlweɪz, tu, ɔfɝɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn kɔʃəs kɝɾəsiz tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ðeɪ pæst, pɝhæps wɪð ə ɡɹiɾɪŋ kɛɹfəli bæləns bɪtwin ən ɪluʒən ʌv ɪkwɑləɾi ən ðə tʃɹu steɪɾ ʌv əfɛɹz, spoʊkən ɪn loʊ vɔɪsəz ðət dɪd nɔɹ kæɹi fɑɹ. ðeɪ pɹuv ði oʊl seɪɪŋ ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ taɪmz meɪk fəɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz. oʊld ɛnməɾiz hæd bɪn pʊɾ əweɪ ɪn ðə feɪs ə nu deɪnʒɝz. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. hɪɹ, tu əɹ θɹi peɪl kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹdz ɪn dɑɹk sɪlk koʊts wɪð θɪn stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌnt, səm wɪð ðə fɹʌns ə ðɛɹ hɛdz ʃeɪvd ən paʊɾɝd soʊlʒɝ-fæʃən, pɹɑməneɪɾɪd əlɔŋsaɪɾ ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ə dɑɹk tɛɹənz, tɔlɝ ɪn ðɛɹ bɹaɪt koʊts wɪð fæt, stʃɹaɪp slivz. ðɛɹ, ə tɛɹən noʊbəlwʊmən ɪn ə snʌɡ pɝl-soʊn kæp, kʌlɝfli bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɡaʊn, ən peɪl leɪs ɹʌf wɔkt ɑɹm-ɪn-ɑɹm bɪsaɪɾ ə ʃɔɹɾɝ kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəl wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ən ɪlæbɹət taʊɝ ðət ɹɛɾid wɛl əbʌv əɹ kəmpænjənz hɛd, smoʊki ɡɹeɪ leɪs ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn, ən nɛɹoʊ stʃɹaɪps ə hɝ haʊs kʌlɝz kæskeɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ waɪd-skɝɾɪd dɑɹk sɪlk. ɔl laɪk bʊzəm-fɹɛnz ən tʃɹʌstɪd kɑnfədæns.

Nobles strolled the hallways, too, offering their own cautious courtesies to the Aes Sedai as they passed, perhaps with a greeting carefully balanced between an illusion of equality and the true state of affairs, spoken in low voices that did nor carry far. They proved the old saying that strange times make for strange traveling companions. Old enmities had been put away in the face of new dangers. For the moment. Here, two or three pale Cairhienin lords in dark silk coats with thin stripes of color across the front, some with the fronts of their heads shaved and powdered soldier-fashion, promenaded alongside an equal number of dark Tairens, taller in their bright coats with fat, striped sleeves. There, a Tairen noblewoman in a snug pearl-sewn cap, colorfully brocaded gown, and pale lace ruff walked arm-in-arm beside a shorter Cairhienin noble with her hair in an elaborate tower that readied well above her companion's head, smoky gray lace under her chin, and narrow stripes of her House colors cascading down the front of her wide-skirted dark silk. All like bosom-friends and trusted confidants.

səm pɛɹɪŋz dɪd lʊk ɑɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz. ə nʌmbɝ ʌv wɪmən hæd bɪɡʌn wɛɹɪŋ aʊtlændɪʃ kloʊðz ə leɪt, əpɛɹənli nɛvɝ noʊɾɪsɪŋ haʊ ðeɪ dʒɹu mɛnz aɪz ən meɪɾ ivən ðə sɝvəns stʃɹʌɡəl nɑt tə stɛɹ. taɪt bɹitʃɪz ən ə koʊt bɛɹli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kʌvɝ ðə hɪps wɝ nɑt suɾəbəl ɡɑɹməns fəɹ ə wʊmən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mʌtʃ ɛfɝt wɛn ɪndə ɹɪtʃ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əɹ pæɾɝnɪŋ ðə koʊt wɪð dʒɛmstoʊnz, dʒuəl nɛkləsɪz ən bɹeɪslɪts ən pɪnz wɪð spɹeɪz ə kʌlɝfəl fɛðɝz oʊnli pɔɪntəɾ ʌp ði ɑɾəti. ən ðoʊz bɹaɪtli daɪd buts, wɪð ðɛɹ hilz ðəɾ æɾəd əz mʌtʃ əz ə hæn tə ə wʊmənz haɪt meɪɾ əm əpɪɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə fɔlɪŋ daʊn wɪð ɛvɹi sweɪɪŋ stɛp.

Some pairings did look odder than others. A number of women had begun wearing outlandish clothes of late, apparently never noticing how they drew men's eyes and made even the servants struggle not to stare. Tight breeches and a coat barely long enough to cover the hips were not suitable garments for a woman, no matter how much effort went into rich embroidery or patterning the coat with gemstones, jeweled necklaces and bracelets and pins with sprays of colorful feathers only pointed up the oddity. And those brightly dyed boots, with their heels that added as much as a hand to a woman's height made them appear in danger of falling down with every swaying step.

"skændələs." sæʃəl mʌɾɝd, aɪɪŋ wʌn sətʃ pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən ən twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɪn dɪsplɛʒɝ.

"Scandalous." Sashalle muttered, eyeing one such pair of women and twitching her skirts in displeasure.

"skændələs," sæmɪtsu mɝmɝd bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑp hɝsɛlf, ðən snæpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt soʊ hɑɹɾ əɹ tiθ klɪkt. ʃi niɾəd tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ tʌŋ. vɔɪsɪŋ əɡɹimən dʒʌs kəz ʃi əɡɹid wɑz ə hæbət ʃi kəɾ ɪl-əfɔɹd wɪð sæʃəl.

"Scandalous," Samitsu murmured before she could stop herself, then snapped her mouth shut so hard her teeth clicked. She needed to control her tongue. Voicing agreement just because she agreed was a habit she could ill-afford with Sashalle.

stɪl ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp ɡlænsɪŋ bæk ət ðə pɛɹ ɪn dɪsəpɹuvəl. ən ə bɪɾ ʌv wʌndɝ. ə jɪɹ əɡoʊ, əleɪn tʃulɪliændɝɾ ən fioʊndə ænɹɪz wʊɾə bɪn əɾ itʃ ʌðɝz θɹoʊts. əɹ ɹæðɝ əv hæd ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts. bʌt ðɛn, hu wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd tə si bɝtoʊm seɪɡən wɔkɪŋ pisfəli wɪð wɪɹɑmɑn sɑniəɡoʊ, niðɝ mæn ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə dæɡɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt? stʃɹeɪnʒ taɪmz ən stʃɹeɪnʒ tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz. daʊtləs ðeɪ wɝ pleɪɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz, mənuvɝɪŋ fəɹ ædvæntɪdʒ əz ðeɪ ɔlweɪz hæd, jɛt dɪvaɪɾɪŋ laɪnz ðət wʌns wɝ ɡɹeɪvən ɪn stoʊn naʊ tɝn aʊt tə hæv bɪn dʒɹɔn ɑn wɔɾɝ ɪnstɛd. vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ taɪmz.

Still she could not help glancing back at the pair in disapproval. And a bit of wonder. A year ago, Alaine Chuliliandred and Fionnda Annariz would have been at each other's throats. Or rather have had their armsmen at one another's throats. But then, who would have expected to see Bertome Saighan walking peacefully with Weiramon Saniago, neither man reaching for the dagger at his belt? Strange times and strange traveling companions. Doubtless they were playing the Game of Houses, maneuvering for advantage as they always had, yet dividing lines that once were graven in stone now turned out to have been drawn on water instead. Very strange times.

ðə kɪtʃənz wɝ ɑn ðə loʊəs lɛvəl ə ðə sʌn pæləs əbʌv ɡɹaʊnd., ət ðə bæk, ə klʌstɝ ə stoʊn-wɔl bim-silɪŋ ɹumz sɛntɝɾ ɝaʊn ə lɔŋ wɪndoʊləs ɹum fʊl ʌv aɪɝn stoʊvz ən bɹɪk ʌvənz ən dʒɹɛst-stoʊn faɪɝpleɪsəz, ən ðə hit wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛniwʌn fɝɡɛt ðə snoʊ aʊtsaɪd, əɹ ivən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz wɪntɝ. nɔɹməli, swɛɾi-feɪst kʊks ən ʌndɝ-kʊks, əz dɑɹkli klæɾ əz ɛni ʌðɝ pæləs sɝvəns bɪniθ ðɛɹ waɪɾ eɪpɹənz, wʊɾə bɪn skɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə pɹipɛɹ ðə mɪddeɪ mil, niɾɪŋ loʊvz ɑn lɔŋ flaʊɝ-stʃɹun teɪbəlz tɑpt wɪð mɑɹbəl, bæstɪŋ ðə dʒɔɪns ən faʊl ðət wɝ tɝnɪŋ ɑn spɪts ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz. naʊ oʊnli ðə tʃɹɑɾɪŋ spɪt-dɑɡz wɝ muvɪŋ, iɡɝ tə ɝn ðɛɹ bɪts fɹəm ðə dʒɔɪns. bæskəts ə tɝnəps ən kæɹəts stʊɾ ənpild ən əŋtʃɑpt, ən smɛlz swiɾ ən spaɪsi keɪm fɹəm ʌntɛndəd pɑts ə sɔsəz. ivən ðə skʌljənz, bɔɪz ən ɡɝlz sɝəptɪʃəsli waɪpɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɑn ðɛɹ eɪpɹənz, stʊɾ ɑn ðə fɹɪnʒ ʌv ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊnd wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz. fɹəm ðə dɔɹ-weɪ, sæmɪtsu kəd si ðə bæk ʌv ən oʊɡiɝz hɛd ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv əm wɛɹ i wɑz siɾəd ət ðə teɪbəl, tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn wʊɾə bɪn stændɪŋ ʌp, ən bɹɔd wɪð ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, kɛɹhinɪn wɝ ʃɔɹt baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, ən ðət hɛlpt. ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn sæʃəlz ɑɹm, ən fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ðə wʊmən stɑpt wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ wɪθaʊt pɹoʊɾɛst.

The kitchens were on the lowest level of the Sun Palace above ground., at the back, a cluster of stone-walled beam-ceiling rooms centered around a long windowless room full of iron stoves and brick ovens and dressed-stone fireplaces, and the heat was enough to make anyone forget the snow outside, or even that it was winter. Normally, sweaty-faced cooks and under-cooks, as darkly clad as any other palace servants beneath their white aprons, would have been scurrying about getting ready to prepare the midday meal, kneading loaves on long flour-strewn tables topped with marble, basting the joints and fowl that were turning on spits in the fireplaces. Now only the trotting spit-dogs were moving, eager to earn their bits from the joints. Baskets of turnips and carrots stood unpeeled and unchopped, and smells sweet and spicy came from untended pots of sauces. Even the scullions, boys and girls surreptitiously wiping their faces on their aprons, stood on the fringe of a group of women clustered around one of the tables. From the door-way, Samitsu could see the back of an Ogier's head rising above them where he was seated at the table, taller than most men would have been standing up, and broad with it. Of course, Cairhienin were short by and large, and that helped. She laid a hand on Sashalle's arm, and for a wonder, the woman stopped where they were without protest.

" . . . vænɪʃt wɪθaʊt livɪŋ ə klu wɛɹ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ?" ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz æskɪŋ ɪn ə dip ɹʌmbəl laɪk ði ɝθ ʃɪftɪŋ. hɪz lɔŋ, tʌftəɾ ɪɹz, stɪkɪŋ ʌp θɹu dɑɹk hɛɹ ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz haɪ kɑlɝ, flɪk bæk ən fɔɹθ ənizəli.

" . . . vanished without leaving a clue where he was going?" the Ogier was asking in a deep rumble like the earth shifting. His long, tufted ears, sticking up through dark hair that hung to his high collar, flicked back and forth uneasily.

"oʊ, də stɑp tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, mæstɝ lɛɾɝ," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs ænsɝɾ ɪn ə kweɪvɝ ðət simd wɛl pɹæktəst. "wɪkəd, hi wɑz. tɔɹ hæf ðə pæləs əpɑɹt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, hi dɪd. hi kəd tɝn jəɹ blʌd tə aɪs dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ ət ju, ən kɪl jə əz sun əz lʊk. θaʊzənz əv daɪd baɪ hɪz oʊn hænd. tɛnz ə θaʊzənz! oʊ aɪ nɛvɝ laɪk tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm."

"Oh, do stop talking about him, Master Ledar," a woman's voice answered in a quaver that seemed well practiced. "Wicked, he was. Tore half the palace apart with the One Power, he did. He could turn your blood to ice just looking at you, and kill you as soon as look. Thousands have died by his own hand. Tens of thousands! Oh I never like talking about him."

"fɔɹ sʌmwʌn əz nɛvɝ laɪks tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ, ɛlʒɹəd mɛθən ənʌðɝ wʊmən sɛd ʃɑɹpli "ju ʃʊɹli tɔk ə lɪɾəl ɛls." staʊɾ ən kwaɪt tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn, nɪɹli əz tɔl əz sæmɪtsu hɝsɛlf wɪð ə fju stʃɹænz ʌv ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɪskeɪpɪŋ əɹ waɪt pleɪn-leɪs kæp, ʃi mʌst əv bɪn ðə tʃif kʊk ɑn duɾi kəz ɛvɹiwʌn sæmɪtsu kəd si kwɪkli nɑɾəd əɡɹimən ən twɪɾɝd wɪð læftɝ ən sɛd, "oʊ, ɹaɪt jə ɑɹ, mɪstʃɹəs bɛldɛɹ," ɪn ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪkəfæntɪk weɪ. sɝvəns hæd ðɛɹ oʊn haɪɹɑɹkiz, əz ɹɪdʒɪdli meɪnteɪn əz ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf.

"For someone as never likes talking about something, Eldrid Methin another woman said sharply "you surely talk of little else." Stout and quite tall for a Cairhienin, nearly as tall as Samitsu herself with a few strands of gray hair escaping her white plain-lace cap, she must have been the chief cook on duty because everyone Samitsu could see quickly nodded agreement and twittered with laughter and said, "Oh, right you are, Mistress Beldair," in a particularly sycophantic way. Servants had their own hierarchies, as rigidly maintained as the Tower itself.

"bʌt ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɹɪli ɪz nɑt fəɹ əs tə bi ɡɑsəpɪŋ oʊvɝ, mæstɝ lɛɾɝ," ðə staʊt wʊmən wɛn ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪznəs, ðəɾ ɪz, ən nɑt fəɹ ðə laɪks ə jə ən mi. tɛl əs mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. hæv jə ɹɪli sin tʃɹɑləks?"

"But that sort of thing really is not for us to be gossiping over, Master Ledar," the stout woman went on Aes Sedai business, that is, and not for the likes of you and me. Tell us more about the Borderlands. Have you really seen Trollocs?"

"ɛɛs sədaɪ," ə mæn mʌɾɝd. hɪɾən baɪ ðə kɹaʊɾ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl, hi hæd tə bi lɛɾɝz kəmpænjən. sæmɪtsu kəd si noʊ ɡɹoʊn mɛn əmʌŋ ðə kɪtʃən-foʊk ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. "tɛl mi, dʒju ɹɪli θɪŋk ðeɪ bɑndəd ðoʊz mɛn jə wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, ðoʊz æʃəmən? əz wɔɹɾɝz? ən wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə wʌn u daɪd? jə nɛvɝ sɛd haʊ."

"Aes Sedai," a man muttered. Hidden by the crowd around the table, he had to be Ledar's companion. Samitsu could see no grown men among the kitchen-folk this morning. "Tell me, do you really think they bonded those men you were talking about, those Asha'man? As Warders? And what about the one who died? You never said how."

"waɪ, ɪt wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz kɪl hɪm," ɛlʒɹəd paɪpt ʌp. "ænd wʌɾ ɛls wəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɑn ə mæn æz? oʊ, tɛɹəbəl, ðeɪ wɑz, ðɛm æʃəmən. tɝn jə tə stoʊn wɪð ə lʊk, ðeɪ kʊd.

"Why, it was the Dragon Reborn as killed him," Eldrid piped up. "And what else would Aes Sedai bond a man as? Oh, terrible, they was, them Asha'man. Turn you to stone with a look, they could.

jə kən tɛl wʌn dʒʌs baɪ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, jə noʊ. fɹaɪtfəl ɡloʊɪŋ aɪz, ðeɪ hæv."

You can tell one just by looking at him, you know. Frightful glowing eyes, they have."

"bi kwaɪət, ɛlʒɹəd," mɪstʃɹəs bɛldɛɹ sɛd fɝmli. "meɪbi ðeɪ wɑz æʃəmən ən meɪbi nɑt, mæstɝ ʌndɝhɪl. meɪbi ðeɪ wɑz bɑndəɾ ən meɪbi nɑt. ɔl aɪ əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kən seɪ ɪz ðeɪ wɑz wɪð hɪm," ði ɛmfəsəs ɪn əɹ vɔɪs meɪd pleɪn u ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt; ɛlʒɹəd maɪt kənsɪɾɝ ɹænd ælθɹ fɪɹfəl bʌt ðɪs wʊmən dɪd nɑt wɑnə soʊ mʌtʃ əz neɪm hɪm, "æn sun æftɝ i lɛft, sʌɾənli ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz tɛlɪŋ əm wʌt tə də ən ðeɪ wɑz duɪŋ ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs ɛni ful noʊz tə də əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛz. ɛniweɪ ðoʊz fɛloʊz ɑɹ ɔl ɡɔn ɔf, naʊ. waɪ ɑɹ jə soʊ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn əm mæstɝ ʌndɝhɪl? ɪz ðəɾ ən ændɔɝən neɪm?"

"Be quiet, Eldrid," Mistress Beldair said firmly. "Maybe they was Asha'man and maybe not, Master Underhill. Maybe they was bonded and maybe not. All I or anyone else can say is they was with him," the emphasis in her voice made plain who she was talking about; Eldrid might consider Rand al'Thor fearful but this woman did not want to so much as name him, "and soon after he left, suddenly the Aes Sedai was telling them what to do and they was doing it. Of course any fool knows to do as an Aes Sedai says. Anyway those fellows are all gone off, now. Why are you so interested in them Master Underhill? Is that an Andoran name?"

lɛɾɝ θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft, ə bumɪŋ saʊn ðət fɪl ðə ɹum. hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt vaɪələnli. "oʊ, wi wɑnə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pleɪsəz wi vɪzət, mɪstʃɹəs bɛldɛɹ. ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, jə seɪ? jə maɪt θɪŋk ɪts koʊl hɪɹ, bʌt wiv sin tʃɹiz kɹæk oʊpən laɪk nʌts ɑn ðə faɪɝ fɹəm ðə koʊld ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. juv blɑks ʌv aɪs ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ, floʊɾɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ʌpstʃɹim, bʌt wiv sin ɹɪvɝz əz waɪɾ əz ði ɑlɡnjə fɹoʊzən soʊ mɝtʃəns kən dʒɹaɪv loʊɾəd tʃɹeɪnz ʌv wæɡənz əkɹɔs ðɛm, ən mɛn fɪʃɪŋ θɹu hoʊlz kʌɾ ɪn aɪs nɪɹli ə spæn θɪk. ət naɪt, ðəɹ ɑɹ ʃits ə laɪɾ ɪn ðə skaɪ ðət sim tə kɹækəl, bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə dɪm ðə stɑɹz, ən " ivən mɪstʃɹəs bɛldɛɹ wɑz linɪŋ təwɔɹdz ði oʊɡiɝ kɑɾ ʌp, bʌt wʌn ə ðə jʌŋ skʌljənz, tu ʃɔɹt tə si pæs ði ədʌls, ɡlæns bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən ɪz aɪz wɛnt waɪd wən ðeɪ lɪɾ ɑn sæmɪtsu ən sæʃəl. hɪz ɡeɪz steɪd fɪkst ɑn əm əz ɪf tʃɹæpt, bʌɾ i fʌmbəld wɪð wʌn hæn tɪl i kəd tʌɡ ət mɪstʃɹəs bɛldɛɹz sliv. ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi ʃʊk ɪm ɔf wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊnd. əɾ ə sɛkən tʌɡ, ʃi hɝ hɛd wɪð ə skaʊl ðət vænɪʃt ɪn ə blɪŋk wən ʃi, tu, sɔ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Ledar threw back his head and laughed, a booming sound that filled the room. His ears twitched violently. "Oh, we want to know everything about the places we visit, Mistress Beldair. The borderlands, you say? You might think its cold here, but we've seen trees crack open like nuts on the fire from the cold in the borderlands. You have blocks of ice on the river, floating down from upstream, but we've seen rivers as wide as the Alguenya frozen so merchants can drive loaded trains of wagons across them, and men fishing through holes cut in ice nearly a span thick. At night, there are sheets of light in the sky that seem to crackle, bright enough to dim the stars, and " Even Mistress Beldair was leaning towards the Ogier caught up, but one of the young scullions, too short to see past the adults, glanced behind him, and his eyes went wide when they lit on Samitsu and Sashalle. His gaze stayed fixed on them as if trapped, but he fumbled with one hand till he could tug at Mistress Beldair's sleeve. The first time she shook him off without looking around. At a second tug, she her head with a scowl that vanished in a blink when she, too, saw the Aes Sedai.

"ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd, heɪstəli tʌkɪŋ stʃɹeɪ hɛɹ bæk ʌndɝ əɹ kæp əz ʃi bɑbd əɹ kɝtsi. "haʊ meɪ aɪ sɝv ju?" lɛɾɝ bɹoʊk ɔf ʃɔɹɾ ɪn mɪd-sɛntəns, ən ɪz ɪɹz stɪfən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹweɪ.

"Grace favor you, Aes Sedai," she said, hastily tucking stray hair back under her cap as she bobbed her curtsy. "How may I serve you?" Ledar broke off short in mid-sentence, and his ears stiffened for a moment. He did not look toward the doorway.

"wi wɪʃ tə spik wɪð jəɹ vɪzəɾɝz" sæʃəl sɛd, muvɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən. "wi woʊn dɪsɹʌp jəɹ kɪtʃən fəɹ lɔŋ."

"We wish to speak with your visitors" Sashalle said, moving into the kitchen. "We won't disrupt your kitchen for long."

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɪf ðə staʊt wʊmən fɛlt ɛni sɝpɹaɪz ət tu sɪstɝz wɑntɪŋ tə tɔk tə kɪtʃən vɪzəɾɝz, ʃi ʃoʊd nʌn. hɛd swɪŋɪŋ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd tə teɪk ɪn ɛvɹiwʌn, ʃi klæpt əɹ plʌmp hænz ən bɪɡæn spaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. "ɛlʒɹəd, ðoʊz tɝnəps wɪl nɛvɝ pil ðɛmsɛlvz. hu wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə fɪɡ sɔs? dʒɹaɪd fɪɡz ɑɹ hɑɹd tə kʌm baɪ! wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ bæstɪŋ spun, kɑsi? ændɪl, ɹʌn fɛtʃ sʌm...' kʊks ən skʌljənz skæɾɝd ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, ən ə klæɾɝ ə pɑts ən spunz kwɪkli fɪl ðə kɪtʃən, ðoʊ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz pleɪnli meɪkɪŋ ən ɛfɝt tə bi əz kwaɪəɾ əz pɑsəbəl soʊ əz nɑt tə dɪstɝb ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ pleɪnli meɪkɪŋ ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə ivən lʊk ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən, ðoʊ ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv səm kəntɔɹʃən.

"Of course, Aes Sedai." If the stout woman felt any surprise at two sisters wanting to talk to kitchen visitors, she showed none. Head swinging from side to side to take in everyone, she clapped her plump hands and began spouting orders. "Eldrid, those turnips will never peel themselves. Who was watching the fig sauce? Dried figs are hard to come by! Where is your basting spoon, Kasi? Andil, run fetch some...' Cooks and scullions scattered in every direction, and a clatter of pots and spoons quickly filled the kitchen, though everyone was plainly making an effort to be as quiet as possible so as not to disturb the Aes Sedai. They were plainly making an effort not to even look in their direction, though that involved some contortion.

ði oʊɡiɝ ɹoʊz tə hɪz fit smuðli hɪz hɛd kʌmɪŋ nɪɹ ðə θɪk silɪŋ bimz. hɪz kloʊðɪŋ wɑz wʌt sæmɪtsu ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm miɾɪŋ oʊɡiɝ bɪfɔɹ, ə lɔŋ dɑɹk koʊt ðət flɛɹɾ oʊvɝ tɝnd-daʊn buts. steɪnz ɑn ɪz koʊt sɛɾ i hæd bɪn tʃɹævlɪŋ hɑɹd; oʊɡiɝ wɝ ə fæstɪɾiəs pipəl. hi oʊnli hæf tɝn tə feɪs əɹ ən sæʃəl ivən əz laɪ meɪɾ ə baʊ, ən laɪ ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz waɪd noʊz əz ɪf ɪɾ ɪtʃt. pɑɹʃəli haɪɾɪŋ ɪz bɹɔd feɪs, bʌɾ i əpɪɹd jʌŋ, fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ. "fɝɡɪv ʌs, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi mɝmɝd, "bʌt wi ɹɪli mʌs bi muvɪŋ ɑn." bɛndɪŋ tə ɡæðɝ ə hjudʒ lɛðɝ skɹɪp ðət hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊl blæŋkɝ taɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ən ʃoʊd ði ɪmpɹɛʃənz ə sɛvɹəl skwɛɹ ʃeɪps pækt ɝaʊnd wʌtɛvɝ ɛls wɑz stʌft ɪnsaɪd, hi hɔɪstəd ðə bɹɔd stʃɹæp oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz kəpeɪʃəs koʊt pɑkəts bʌlʒd wɪð æŋɡjəlɝ ʃeɪps, tu. "wi hæv ə lɔŋ weɪ tə ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl." hɪz kəmpænjən ɹɪmeɪn siɾəd, ðoʊ, hɪz hænz spɹɛɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp, ə peɪl-hɛɹd jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə wiks ɡɹoʊθ ə bɪɹɾ u sim tə hæv slɛp mɔɹ ðən wʌn naɪɾ ɪn ɪz ɹʌmpəl bɹaʊn koʊt. hi wɑtʃt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛɹəli, wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ðət bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə kɔɹnɝd fɑks.

The Ogier rose to his feet smoothly his head coming near the thick ceiling beams. His clothing was what Samitsu remembered from meeting Ogier before, a long dark coat that flared over turned-down boots. Stains on his coat said he had been traveling hard; Ogier were a fastidious people. He only half turned to face her and Sashalle even as lie made a bow, and lie rubbed at his wide nose as if it itched. Partially hiding his broad face, but he appeared young, for an Ogier. "Forgive us, Aes Sedai," he murmured, "but we really must be moving on." Bending to gather a huge leather scrip that had a large rolled blanker tied across the top and showed the impressions of several square shapes packed around whatever else was stuffed inside, he hoisted the broad strap over one shoulder. His capacious coat pockets bulged with angular shapes, too. "We have a long way to go before nightfall." His companion remained seated, though, his hands spread on the tabletop, a pale-haired young man with a week's growth of beard who seemed to have slept more than one night in his rumpled brown coat. He watched the Aes Sedai warily, with dark eyes that belonged on a cornered fox.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ ðət jə kən ɹitʃ baɪ naɪtfɔl?" sæʃəl dɪd nɑt stɑp əntɪl ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə jʌŋ oʊɡiɝ, kloʊs ɪnʌf tə nid tə kɹeɪn əɹ nɛk tə lʊk ʌp ət hɪm, ðoʊ ʃi meɪɾ ɪt sim ɡɹeɪsfəl ɹæðɝ ðən ɑkwɝd, əz ɪt ʃəɾ əv bɪn. "ɑɹ jə ɑn jəɹ weɪ tə ðə miɾɪŋ wiv hɝɾ əbaʊt, ɪn slɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ mæstɝ . . . lɛɾɝ, ɪz ɪt?" hɪz tɔl ɪɹz twɪtʃt vaɪələnli, ðən wɝ stɪl, ən ɪz tikʌp-saɪzd aɪz nɛɹoʊɾ ɔlmoʊst əz wɛɹəli əz ðə jʌŋ mænz, tɪl ðə dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɛnz ə hɪz aɪbɹaʊz tʃɹeɪld ɑntu hɪz tʃiks-"lɛɾɝ, sʌn ə ʃændɪn sʌn ə kɔɪməl, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "bʌɾ aɪm sɝɾənli nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹæn stʌmp. waɪ, ði ɛldɝz wʊdn lemi kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ wʌt wɑz biɪŋ sɛd." hi ɡeɪv ə dip bæs tʃʌkəl ðət saʊndəd fɔɹst.

"Where are you going that you can reach by nightfall?" Sashalle did not stop until she was standing in front of the young Ogier, close enough to need to crane her neck to look up at him, though she made it seem graceful rather than awkward, as it should have been. "Are you on your way to the meeting we've heard about, in Sledding Shangtai Master . . . Ledar, is it?" His tall ears twitched violently, then were still, and his teacup-sized eyes narrowed almost as warily as the young man's, till the dangling ends of his eyebrows trailed onto his cheeks-"Ledar, son of Shandin son of Koimal, Aes Sedai," he said reluctantly. "But I'm certainly not going to the Grand Stump. Why, the Elders wouldn't let me close enough to hear what was being said." He gave a deep bass chuckle that sounded forced.

"wi kænt ɡɛt wɛɹ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tənaɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi liɡ bɪhaɪn əs ɪz ə liɡ wi doʊn əv tə wɔk təmɑɹoʊ. wi nid tə bi ɑn əɹ weɪ." ði ənʃeɪvən jʌŋ mæn stʊɾ ʌp, ɹʌnɪŋ ə hænd nɝvəsli əlɔŋ ðə lɔŋ hɪlt ə ðə sɔɹd bʌkəld əɾ ɪz weɪst, jɛɾ i meɪd noʊ muv tə pɪk ʌp ðə skɹɪp ən blæŋkət-ɹoʊl əɾ ɪz fiɾ ən fɑloʊ əz ði oʊɡiɝ stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ ðət lɛd tə ðə stʃɹit, ivən wən ði oʊɡiɝ sɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "wi nid tə ɡoʊ naʊ, kɑɹldɪn." sæʃəl ɡlaɪɾɪd fludli ɪndə ði oʊɡiɝz pæθ, ðoʊ ʃi hæd tə teɪk θɹi stʃɹaɪdz tə hɪz wʌn, "ju wɝ æskɪŋ æftɝ wɝk əz ə meɪsən, mæstɝ lɛɾɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn toʊnz bɹʊkɪŋ noʊ nɑnsɛns, "bʌt jəɹ hænz ɑɹ nɑɾ əz kælʌzd əz ɛni meɪsənz aɪv ɛvɝ sin. ɪt wəd bi bɛs fəɹ jə tə ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃənz."

"We can't get where we're going tonight, Aes Sedai, but every league behind us is a league we don't have to walk tomorrow. We need to be on our way." The unshaven young man stood up, running a hand nervously along the long hilt of the sword buckled at his waist, yet he made no move to pick up the scrip and blanket-roll at his feet and follow as the Ogier started toward the door that led to the street, even when the Ogier said over his shoulder, "We need to go now, Karldin." Sashalle glided fluidly into the Ogier's path, though she had to take three strides to his one, "You were asking after work as a mason, Master Ledar," she said in tones brooking no nonsense, "but your hands are not as callused as any mason's I've ever seen. It would be best for you to answer my questions."

səpɹɛsɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪʌmfən smaɪl, sæmɪtsu muvd ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ. soʊ sæʃəl θɔt ʃi kəd sɪmpli pʊʃ əɹ əsaɪɾ ən fɛɹəɾ aʊt wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, dɪd ʃi? ðə wʊmən wɑz ɪn fəɹ ə sɝpɹaɪz. "ju ɹɪli mʌst steɪ ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ," ʃi sɛd tə ði oʊɡiɝ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs; ðə nɔɪz ɪn ðə kɪtʃən ʃəd kip ɛniwʌn fɹəm oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə teɪk tʃænsəz. "wɛn aɪ keɪm tə ðə sʌn pæləs, aɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hɝɾ ʌv ə jʌŋ oʊɡiɝ, ə fɹɛn ə ɹænd ælθɹ. hi lɛf kɛɹhin səm mʌnθs pæst, ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ə jʌŋ mæn neɪm kɑɹldɪn, ɪzən ðət ɹaɪt, lɔɪəl?' ði oʊɡiɝz ɪɹz wɪltɪd.

Suppressing a triumphant smile, Samitsu moved up beside the Red sister. So Sashalle thought she could simply push her aside and ferret out what was going on, did she? The woman was in for a surprise. "You really must stay a while longer," she said to the Ogier in a low voice; the noise in the kitchen should keep anyone from overhearing, yet there was no need to take chances. "When I came to the Sun Palace, I had already heard of a young Ogier, a friend of Rand al'Thor. He left Cairhien some months past, in company with a young man named Karldin, Isn't that right, Loial?' The Ogier's ears wilted.

ðə jʌŋ mæn bɪɾ ɔf ə kɔɹs kɝs i ʃʊɾə noʊn bɛɾɝ ðən tə maʊð ɪn fɹʌn ə sɪstɝz. "aɪ liv wən aɪ wɑnə liv, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi sɛd hɑɹʃli", bʌɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, laɪ dɪvaɪɾəd ɪz ɡeɪz bɪtwin əɹ ən sæʃəl, jɛɾ i wɑz wɑtʃfəl fəɹ ɛni ʌv ðə kɪtʃən wɝkɝz u maɪt kʌm nɪɹ. hi dɪd nɔɹ wɪʃ tə bi oʊvɝhɝd, iðɝ. "bɪfɔɹ aɪ du, aɪ wɑn səm ænsɝz. wʌt hæpən tə ... maɪ fɹɛnz? ən hɪm. dɪɾ i ɡoʊ mæd?" lɔɪəl saɪd hɛvəli, ən meɪɾ ə pæsəfaɪɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝ wɪð wʌn hjudʒ hænd, "bi izi. kɑɹldɪn," bi mɝmɝd, "ɹænd wʊdn laɪk jə stɑɹɾɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. bi izi." kɑɹldɪnz skaʊl oʊnli dipənd.

The young man bit off a coarse curse he should have known better than to mouth in front of sisters. "I leave when I want to leave, Aes Sedai," he said harshly", but in a low voice. For the most part, lie divided his gaze between her and Sashalle, yet he was watchful for any of the kitchen workers who might come near. He did nor wish to be overheard, either. "Before I do, I want some answers. What happened to ... my friends? And him. Did he go mad?" Loial sighed heavily, and made a pacifying gesture with one huge hand, "Be easy. Karldin," be murmured, "Rand wouldn't like you starting trouble with Aes Sedai. Be easy." Karldin's scowl only deepened.

əbɹʌpli ɪɾ əkɝd tə sæmɪtsu ðət ʃi cʊɾə hændəl ðɪs bɛɾɝ. ðoʊz wɝ nɔɹ ði aɪz ʌv ə kɔɹnɝd fɑks, bʌɾ ə wʊlf. ʃi bæd ɡɹoʊn tu əkʌstəm tə deɪmɝ ən dʒɑhɹ ən ɛbən, seɪfli bɑndəɾ ən teɪmd. ðət maɪt bi ən oʊvɝsteɪtmənt, ðoʊ mɛɹaɪs wɑz meɪkɪŋ ən ɛfɝt wɪð dʒɑhɹ-ðæt wɑz mɛɹaɪsəz weɪ-jɛɾ ɪt sim ðə hɔɹɝ ə jɛstɝdeɪ kəd bɪkʌm ðə kəmpleɪsənsi ʌv tədeɪ æftɝ lɔŋ ɪnʌf ɪkspoʊʒɝ. kɑɹldɪn mænfɝ wɑz ən æʃəmən, tu, ən niðɝ bɑndəd nɔɹ teɪm. wɑz i ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ? ʃi ɔlmoʊs læft. dɪd bɝdz flaɪ?

Abruptly it occurred to Samitsu that she could have handled this better. Those were nor the eyes of a cornered fox, but a wolf. She bad grown too accustomed to Damer and Jahar and Eben, safely bonded and tamed. That might be an overstatement, though Merise was making an effort with Jahar-that was Merise's way-yet it seemed the horror of yesterday could become the complacency of today after long enough exposure. Karldin Manfor was an Asha'man, too, and neither bonded nor tame. Was he embracing the male half of the Power? She almost laughed. Did birds fly?

sæʃəl wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə stʌɾiɪŋ fɹaʊn, hɝ hænz mʌtʃ tu stɪl ɑn əɹ skɝts, bʌt sæmɪtsu wɑz ɡlæd nɑt tə si ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɝaʊn hɝ. æʃəmən kəd fil wən ə wʊmən hɛl ðə paʊɝ, ən ðət maɪt meɪk ɪm ækt . . . pɹɪsɪpɪɾətli. sɝɾənli ʃi ən sæmɪtsu təɡɛðɝ kəd hændəl hɪm-kʊd ðeɪ, ɪf i ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl ðə paʊɝ? ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ kʊd-ʌv kɔɹs! - bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv tə.

Sashalle was watching the young man with a studying frown, her hands much too still on her skirts, but Samitsu was glad not to see the light of saidar around her. Asha'man could feel when a woman held the Power, and that might make him act . . . precipitately. Certainly she and Samitsu together could handle him-could they, if he already held the Power? Of course, they could-Of course! - but it would be much better if they did not have to.

sæʃəl sɝɾənli wɑz meɪkɪŋ noʊ muv tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ, naʊ, soʊ sæmɪtsu leɪɾ ə hæn laɪtli ɑn ɪz lɛft ɑɹm. θɹu hɪz koʊt sliv, ɪt fɛlt laɪk ə bɑɹ ʌv aɪɝn. soʊ hi wɑz əz ənizi əz ʃi. əz ənizi əz ʃi?

Sashalle certainly was making no move to take charge, now, so Samitsu laid a hand lightly on his left arm. Through his coat sleeve, it felt like a bar of iron. So he was as uneasy as she. As uneasy as she?

laɪt, bʌt deɪmɝ ən ðoʊz ʌðɝ tu hæd spɔɪld ɔl əɹ ɪnstɪŋks!

Light, but Damer and those other two had spoiled all her instincts!

"hi sim seɪn əz moʊs mɛn wən aɪ læst sɔ hɪm," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, wɪð dʒʌst ə slaɪɾ ɛmfəsəs.

"He seemed sane as most men when I last saw him," she said softly, with just a slight emphasis.

nʌn ə ðə kɪtʃən-foʊk wɝ nɪɹbaɪ, bʌɾ ə fju hæd bɪɡʌn snikɪŋ piks təwɔɹd ðə teɪbəl. lɔɪəl ɛksheɪl hɛvəli ɪn ɹɪlif ə saʊn laɪk wɪn ɹʌʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə maʊθ ʌv ə keɪv, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əɹ ətɛnʃən ɑn kɑɹldɪn. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ i ɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz əlaɪv əz ʌv ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ." ɑlɑnə hæd bɪn kloʊsəməðd əz ə mʌsəl bɪɑn ðæt, ən oʊvɝ-bɛɹɪŋ, tu, wɪð kædzueɪnz noʊɾ ɪn əɹ fɪst. "fɛdwɪn mɔɹ daɪɾ ə pɔɪzən, aɪ fɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə hu ɡeɪv ɪt tə hɪm." tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, kɑɹldɪn mɪɹli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, wɪð ə ɹufəl ɡɹɪmɑs, ən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl əbaʊt waɪn. "æz fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm wɔɹɾɝz ə ðɛɹ oʊn fɹi wɪl." əz mʌtʃ əz ɛni mæn dɪɾ ɛni θɪŋ ə hɪz fɹi wɪl. hɝ ɹɑʃən sɝɾənli hæd nɑt wɑntəd tə bi ə wɔɹɾɝ, əntɪl ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪm fəɹ wʌn. ivən ə wʊmən u wɑz nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd juʒəwəli meɪk ə mæn dɪsaɪd ðə weɪ ʃi wɑntəd. 'ðeɪ' θɔɾ ɪɾ ə bɛɾɝ tʃɔɪs, seɪfɝ, ðən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ... ði ʌðɝz laɪk ju. jə si, ðə dæmədʒ hɪɹ wɑz dʌn wɪð seɪɾɪn. jə ʌndɝstæn u mʌst əv bɪn bɪhaɪn ɪt? ɪt wɑz ən ətɛmp tə kɪl ðə wʌn huz sænəɾi jə fɪɹ fɔɹ."

None of the kitchen-folk were nearby, but a few had begun sneaking peeks toward the table. Loial exhaled heavily in relief a sound like wind rushing across the mouth of a cave, but she kept her attention on Karldin. "I don't know where he is, but he was alive as of a few days ago." Alanna had been closemouthed as a mussel beyond that, and over-bearing, too, with Cadsuane's note in her fist. "Fedwin Morr died of poison, I fear, but I have no idea who gave it to him." To her surprise, Karldin merely shook his head, with a rueful grimace, and muttered something incomprehensible about wine. "As for the others, they became Warders of their own free will." As much as any man did any thing of his free will. Her Roshan certainly had not wanted to be a Warder, until she decided she wanted him for one. Even a woman who was not Aes Sedai could usually make a man decide the way she wanted. 'They' thought it a better choice, safer, than returning to ... the others like you. You see, the damage here was done with saidin. You understand who must have been behind it? It was an attempt to kill the one whose sanity you fear for."

ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə sɝpɹaɪz hɪm, iðɝ. wʌt sɔɹɾ ə mɛn wɝ ðiz æʃəmən? wɑz ðɛɹ soʊ-kɔl blæk taʊɝ ə mɝɾɝ-pɪt? ðə taɪtnəs wɛn aʊɾ ə hɪz ɑɹm, ðoʊ, ən sʌɾənli hi wɑz dʒʌst ə ɹoʊd-wɪɹi jʌŋ mæn u niɾəd ə ʃeɪv. "laɪt!" hi bɹiðd. "wʌt də wi də naʊ, lɔɪəl? wɛɹ də wi ɡoʊ?"

That did not seem to surprise him, either. What sort of men were these Asha'man? Was their so-called Black Tower a murder-pit? The tightness went out of his arm, though, and suddenly he was just a road-weary young man who needed a shave. "Light!" he breathed. "What do we do now, Loial? Where do we go?"

"aɪ ... doʊnt noʊ" lɔɪəl ɹɪplaɪd, hɪz ʃoʊldɝz sæɡɪŋ taɪɹədli ən ɪz lɔŋ ɪɹz dʒɹupɪŋ. "aɪ  wɪv tə faɪn hɪm, kɑɹldɪn. sʌmhaʊ. wi kæn': ɡɪv ʌp naʊ. wɪv tə lɝ ɪm noʊ wi dɪd wʌɾ i æskt. əz mʌtʃ əz wi kʊd."

"I ... don't know" Loial replied, his shoulders sagging tiredly and his long ears drooping. "I  We have to find him, Karldin. Somehow. We can': give up now. We have to ler him know we did what he asked. As much as we could."

ən wʌt wɑz ɪɾ ælθɹ hæɾ æskt, sæmɪtsu wʌndɝd. wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, ʃi kəd lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil fɹəm ðiz tu. ə taɪɝd mæn, əɹ oʊɡiɝ, filɪŋ lɔst ən əloʊn, wɑz ɹaɪp fəɹ ænsɝɪŋ kwɛstʃənz.

And what was it al'Thor had asked, Samitsu wondered. With a little luck, she could learn a great deal from these two. A tired man, or Ogier, feeling lost and alone, was ripe for answering questions.

kɑɹldɪn ɡeɪv ə smɔl dʒʌmp, hɪz hæn taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn ɪz sɔɹdhɪlt, ən ʃi bɪt bæk ə kɝs ə hɝ oʊn əz ə pæləs sɝvɪŋ wʊmən keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum wɪð əɹ skɝts ɡæðɝɾ ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ niz.

Karldin gave a small jump, his hand tightening on his swordhilt, and she bit back a curse of her own as a palace serving woman came running into the room with her skirts gathered almost to her knees.

"lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪnz bɪn mɝɾɝd!" ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən skwild. "wi wɪl ɔl bi kɪld ɪn əɹ bɛdz! maɪ aɪz əv sin ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ, oʊl mɹɪŋɡəl hɪmsɛlf, ən maɪ mæm sɛz spɪɹəts wɪl kɪl jə ɪf ðəɹ əz bɪn ə mɝɾɝ dʌn! ðeɪ-!" hɝ maʊθ fɹoʊz oʊpən wən ʃi kɑt ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ʃi skɪɾəd tə ə hɔl stɪl klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts. ðə kɪtʃən foʊk sim fɹoʊzən, tu, ɔl wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðɛɹ aɪz tə si wʌt ðeɪ wəd du.

"Lord Dobraine's been murdered!" the serving woman squealed. "We will all be killed in our beds! My eyes have seen the dead walking, old Maringil himself, and my Mam says spirits will kill you if there has been a murder done! They-!" Her mouth froze open when she caught the presence of Aes Sedai, and she skidded to a halt still clutching her skirts. The kitchen folk seemed frozen, too, all watching the Aes Sedai from the corners of their eyes to see what they would do.

"nɑt dɑbɹeɪn," lɔɪəl moʊnd, ɪɹz laɪɪŋ flæɾ əɡɛnst ɪz hɛd. "nɑt hɪm." hi lʊkt əz mʌtʃ æŋɡɹi əz sæɾənd, hɪz feɪs stoʊni. sæmɪtsu dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ən oʊɡiɝ æŋɡɹi.

"Not Dobraine," Loial moaned, ears lying flat against his head. "Not him." He looked as much angry as saddened, his face stony. Samitsu did not think she had ever seen an Ogier angry.

"wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?" sæʃəl dɪmændəɾ ə ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən bɪfɔɹ sæmɪtsu kəɾ ivən pɑɹɾ əɹ lɪps. "haʊ dʒju noʊ hi wɑz mɝɾɝd? haʊ dʒju noʊ hiz dɛd?" ðə wʊmən swɑloʊd, hɝ aɪz hɛl baɪ sæʃəlz kul ɡeɪz. "sɛɹə, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ʃi sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli, bɛndɪŋ əɹ niz ɪn ə kɝtsi ən oʊnli ðən ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi stɪl hæɾ əɹ skɝts ɡæðɝɾ ʌp. heɪstəli smuðɪŋ əm daʊn oʊnli sim tə flʌstɝ əɹ mɔɹ. "sɛɹə dɑfnəl? ðeɪ seɪ . . . ɛvɹibɑɾi sɛz lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn ɪz... aɪ min, hi wɑz ... aɪ min . . ." ʃi swɑloʊɾ əɡɛn, hɑɹd. "ðeɪ ɔl seɪ hɪz ɹumz ɑɹ kʌvɝd wɪð blʌd. hi wɑz faʊn laɪɪŋ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt pul ʌv ɪt. wɪð ɪz hɛd kɝ ɔf, ðeɪ seɪ."

"What is your name?" Sashalle demanded of the serving woman before Samitsu could even part her lips. "How do you know he was murdered? How do you know he's dead?" The woman swallowed, her eyes held by Sashalle's cool gaze. "Cera, Aes Sedai?" she said hesitantly, bending her knees in a curtsy and only then realizing that she still had her skirts gathered up. Hastily smoothing them down only seemed to fluster her more. "Cera Dofnal? They say . . . Everybody says Lord Dobraine is... I mean, he was ... I mean . . ." She swallowed again, hard. "They all say his rooms are covered with blood. He was found lying in a great pool of it. With his head cur off, they say."

"ðeɪ seɪ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz," sæʃəl sɛd ɡɹɪmli, "æn juʒəwəli ðəɹ ɹɔŋ. sæmɪtsu, jəl kʌm wɪð mi. ɪf lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn əz bɪn ɪnʒɝd, jə meɪ bi eɪbəl tə də sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. lɔɪəl, kɑɹldɪn, jə kʌm, tu, aɪ doʊnt wɑn jə aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt bɪfɔɹ aɪ hæv ə tʃæns tə æsk ə fju kwɛstʃənz."

"They say a great many things," Sashalle said grimly, "and usually they're wrong. Samitsu, you will come with me. If Lord Dobraine has been injured, you may be able to do something for him. Loial, Karldin, you come, too, I don't want you out of my sight before I have a chance to ask a few questions."

"bɝn jəɹ kwɛstʃənz!" ðə jʌŋ æʃəmən ɡɹaʊld, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz. "aɪm livɪŋ!" "noʊ, kɑɹldɪn," lɔɪəl sɛd dʒɛnli, leɪɪŋ ə hjudʒ hæn ɑn ɪz kəmpænjənz ʃoʊldɝ. "wi kænt ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ wi noʊ əbaʊt dɑbɹeɪn. hiz ə fɹɛnd, ɹændz fɹɛnd, ən maɪn. wi kænt. ɛniweɪ, wɛɹ ɑɹ wi hɝiɪŋ tə?" kɑɹldɪn lʊkt əweɪ.

"Burn your questions!" the young Asha'man growled, shouldering his belongings. "I'm leaving!" "No, Karldin," Loial said gently, laying a huge hand on his companion's shoulder. "We can't go before we know about Dobraine. He's a friend, Rand's friend, and mine. We cant. Anyway, where are we hurrying to?" Karldin looked away.

hi hæd noʊ ænsɝ, sæmɪtsu skwizd əɹ aɪz ʃʌt, ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɛlp fəɹ ɪt. ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf fɑloʊɪŋ sæʃəl aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃənz, wʌns mɔɹ hɝiɪŋ tə kip ʌp wɪð ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz kwɪk, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ stʃɹaɪd. ɪn fækt ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf hæf-ɹʌnɪŋ; sæʃəl sɛɾ ən ivən mɔɹ ɹæpəd peɪs ðən bɪfɔɹ.

He had no answer, Samitsu squeezed her eyes shut, and took a deep breath, but there was no help for it. She found herself following Sashalle out of the kitchens, once more hurrying to keep up with the other woman's quick, gliding stride. In fact she found herself half-running; Sashalle set an even more rapid pace than before.

ðə bæbəlɪŋ ə vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz bɪhaɪn əm əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ aʊt ðə dɔɹ. ðə kɪtʃən foʊk pɹɑbli ɔl wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən fəɹ pɝtɪkjəlɝz, dɪteɪlz ʃi vɛɹi laɪkli wəɾ ɪnvɛnt wɛɹ əɹ nɑlədʒ feɪld. tɛn dɪfɹən vɝʒənz ʌv ɪvɛns wəd faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðət kɪtʃən, ɪf nɑɾ əz mɛni əz ðəɹ wɝ kɪtʃən foʊk. wɝst ʌv ɔl, tɛn dɪfɹən vɝʒənz ʌv ɪvɛns ɪn ðə kɪtʃən wəd faɪn ðɛɹ weɪ aʊt, ɛvɹi wʌn æɾɪŋ tə ðə ɹumɝz kɔɹɡeɪd, daʊtləs wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stɑɹɾɪŋ. ʃi kəd hɑɹdli ɹikɔl ə deɪ ðət hæd ɡɔn soʊ bædli fəɹ hɝ, soʊ sʌɾənli laɪk slɪpɪŋ ɑn wʌn pætʃ ʌv aɪs oʊnli tə faɪn ənʌðɝ ʌndɝ əɹ fit, ðən ənʌðɝ. kædzueɪn wəɾ əv əɹ haɪd tə meɪk ɡlʌvz æftɝ ðɪs!

The babbling of voices rose behind them as soon as they were out the door. The kitchen folk probably all were pressing the serving woman for particulars, details she very likely would invent where her knowledge failed. Ten different versions of events would find their way out of that kitchen, if not as many as there were kitchen folk. Worst of all, ten different versions of events in the kitchen would find their way out, every one adding to the rumors Corgaide, doubtless was already starting. She could hardly recall a day that had gone so badly for her, so suddenly like slipping on one patch of ice only to find another under her feet, then another. Cadsuane would have her hide to make gloves after this!

ət lis lɔɪəl ən kɑɹldɪn tʃɹeɪld æftɝ sæʃəl əz wɛl. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi lɝn fɹəm əm maɪt stɪl bi pʊt tə ædvæntɪdʒ, ə weɪ tə sælvədʒ sʌmθɪŋ. skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ət sæʃəlz saɪd, ʃi stʌɾid əm ɪn bɹif ɡlænsɪz oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. teɪkɪŋ ʃɔɹt stʃɹaɪdz tə kip fɹəm oʊvɝ-ɹʌnɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn wɝi. oʊvɝ dɑbɹeɪn, vɛɹi laɪkli bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ pɝhæps oʊvɝ oʊnli kəmpliɾɪŋ ɪz mɪstɪɹiəs tæsk "æz wɛl əz i kʊd? ðət wɑz ə mɪstɝi ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə sɑlv. ðə jʌŋ æʃəmən hæd noʊ dɪfəkəlti kipɪŋ ʌp ðoʊ hi wɔɹ ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ə stʌbɝn ɹɪlʌktəns ən ɪz hæn kɝɛst ɪz sɔɹdhɪlt. ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪn ɪm dɪd nɑt laɪ ɪn stil. hi stɛɹd səspɪʃəsli ət ðə bæks ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əhɛd, wʌns miɾɪŋ sæmɪtsuz ɡlæns wɪð ə dɑɹk ɡlaʊɝ. hi hæd ðə sɛns tə kip ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt, ðoʊ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə faɪn ə weɪ tə pɹaɪ ɪɾ oʊpən leɪɾɝ fəɹ mɔɹ ðən snɑɹlɪŋ.

At least Loial and Karldin trailed after Sashalle as well. Whatever she learned from them might still be put to advantage, a way to salvage something. Scurrying along at Sashalle's side, she studied them in brief glances over her shoulder. Taking short strides to keep from over-running the Aes Sedai, the Ogier was frowning in worry. Over Dobraine, very likely but also perhaps over only completing his mysterious task "as well as he could? That was a mystery she intended to solve. The young Asha'man had no difficulty keeping up though he wore an expression of stubborn reluctance and his hand caressed his swordhilt. The danger in him did not lie in steel. He stared suspiciously at the backs of the Aes Sedai ahead, once meeting Samitsu's glance with a dark glower. He had the sense to keep his mouth shut, though. She would have to find a way to pry it open later for more than snarling.

sæʃəl nɛvɝ ɡlæns bɪhaɪn tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə pɛɹ wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, ʃi hæd tə hɪɹ ðə θʌɾ ə ði oʊɡiɝz buts ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. hɝ feɪs wɑz θɔtfəl ən sæmɪtsu wʊɾə ɡɪvən ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. sæʃəl maɪt bi oʊθswɔɹn tə ɹænd ælθɹ, bʌt wʌt pɹətɛkʃən dɪd ðət ɡɪv tə ən æʃəmən? ʃi wɑz ɹɛd, æftɝ ɔl. ðət hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd wɪð əɹ feɪs.

Sashalle never glanced behind to make sure the pair were following, but then, she had to hear the thud of the Ogier's boots on the floor tiles. Her face was thoughtful and Samitsu would have given a great deal to know what she was thinking. Sashalle might be oathsworn to Rand al'Thor, but what protection did that give to an Asha'man? She was Red, after all. That had not changed with her face.

laɪt, ðɪs kəd bi ðə wɝs pætʃ ʌv aɪs ʌv ɔl!

Light, this could be the worst patch of ice of all!
