ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ ɑɹdʒuəs klaɪm fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz tə lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪnz əpɑɹtməns ɪn ðə taʊɝ ə ðə fʊl mun, wɪtʃ wɑz juʒəwəli sɛɾ əsaɪd fəɹ vɪzəɾɪŋ noʊbɪləɾi ʌv haɪ ɹæŋk, ən ɔl əlɔŋ ðə weɪ, sæmɪtsu sɔ ði ɛvəɾəns ðət sɛɹə hæd bɪn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə fɝs tə hɪɹ wʌt ði ɛvɝ-ənɑnəməs ðeɪ hæd tə seɪ.

It was a long arduous climb from the kitchens to Lord Dobraine's apartments in the Tower of the Full Moon, which was usually set aside for visiting nobility of high rank, and all along the way, Samitsu saw the evidence that Cera had been far from the first to hear what the ever-anonymous they had to say.

ɹæðɝ ðən ɛnləs stʃɹimz ə sɝvəns boʊɪŋ əlɔŋ daɪ kɔɹɪɾɝz, smɔl ɪksaɪɾəd nɑts stʊd wɪspɝɪŋ æŋkʃəsli. ət saɪɾ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðeɪ spɹæŋ əpɑɹɾ ən skɝiɾ əweɪ. ə hændfʊl dɪd ɡeɪp ət siɪŋ ən oʊɡiɝ stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə pæləs, jɛt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ðeɪ ɔl bʌt flɛd. ðə noʊbəlz ðət hæd bɪn əbaʊt bɪfɔɹ hæɾ ɔl vænɪʃt, daʊtləs bæk tə ðɛɹ oʊn ɹumz tə mʌl oʊvɝ wʌɾ ɑpɝtunəɾiz ən hæzɝdz dɑbɹeɪnz dɛθ əfɔɹɾəd ðɛm. wʌtɛvɝ sæʃəl θɔt, sæmɪtsu noʊ lɔŋɡɝ daʊɾɪd. ɪf dɑbɹeɪn hæd bɪn əlaɪv, hɪz oʊn sɝvəns wʊɾə pʊt peɪd tə ðə ɹumɝ ɔlɹɛɾi, fəɹ fɝðɝ kɑnfɝmeɪʃən, ðə hɔlweɪz aʊtsaɪd dɑbɹeɪnz ɹumz wɝ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð æʃən-feɪst sɝvəns, ðɛɹ slivz ɹɪŋ tə ði ɛlboʊz ɪn ðə blu-ænd-waɪɾ ə haʊs tæbɔɹwɪn. səm wɛpt, ən ʌðɝz lʊk lɔst, ðɛɹ faʊndeɪʃən stoʊn pʊld aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðɛm. əɾ ə wɝd fɹəm sæʃəl, ðeɪ stʊɾ əsaɪd fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, muvɪŋ dʒɹʌŋkənli əɹ məkænɪkli. deɪzd aɪz swɛp baɪ ði oʊɡiɝ wɪθaʊɾ æktʃəli  ɹɛdʒɪstɝɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ sɔ. fju ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə meɪk ivən hæfhɑɹɾɪd kɝɾəsiz.

Rather than endless streams of servants Bowing along die corridors, small excited knots stood whispering anxiously. At sight of the Aes Sedai, they sprang apart and scurried away. A handful did gape at seeing an Ogier striding through the palace, yet for the most part, they all but fled. The nobles that had been about before had all vanished, doubtless back to their own rooms to mull over what opportunities and hazards Dobraine's death afforded them. Whatever Sashalle thought, Samitsu no longer doubted. If Dobraine had been alive, his own servants would have put paid to the rumor already, For further confirmation, the hallways outside Dobraine's rooms were crowded with ashen-faced servants, their sleeves ringed to the elbows in the blue-and-white of House Taborwin. Some wept, and others looked lost, their foundation stone pulled out from under them. At a word from Sashalle, they stood aside for the Aes Sedai, moving drunkenly or mechanically. Dazed eyes swept by the Ogier without actually registering what they saw. Few remembered to make even halfhearted courtesies.

ɪnsaɪd, ði æntəɹum wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz fʊl ə dɑbɹeɪnz sɝvəns, moʊst stɛɹɪŋ əz ɪf pɑliækst.

Inside, the anteroom was almost as full of Dobraine's servants, most staring as if poleaxed.

dɑbɹeɪn hɪmsɛlf leɪ moʊʃənləs ɑn ə lɪɾɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹum, hɪz hɛd stɪl ətætʃt tə hɪz bɑɾi bʌɾ ɪz aɪz kloʊzd ən ə dʒɹaɪɪŋ ʃiɾ ə blʌd, fɹəm ə lɔŋ kʌɾ ɪn ɪz skælp, spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪz stɪl fitʃɝz. ə dɑɹk tʃɹɪkəl hæd lik fɹəm ɪz slæk maʊθ. tu sɝvɪŋ mɛn wɪð tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃiks pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə leɪɪŋ ə waɪt klɔθ oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs ət ði ɛntʃɹəns ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Dobraine himself lay motionless on a litter in the middle of the large room, his head still attached to his body but his eyes closed and a drying sheet of blood, from a long cut in his scalp, spread across his still features. A dark trickle had leaked from his slack mouth. Two serving men with tears streaming down their cheeks paused in the act of laying a white cloth over his face at the entrance of the Aes Sedai.

dɑbɹeɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə bi bɹiðɪŋ, ən ðəɹ wɝ blʌdsteɪnd ɡæʃəz ɪn ðə tʃɛst ə hɪz koʊt, wɪð ɪts θɪn stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ ðət mɑɹtʃt daʊn tə hɪz niz. bɪsaɪd ðə lɪɾɝ, ə dɑɹk blɑt lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə mænz bɑɾi mɑɹd ðə ɡɹin-ænd-jɛloʊ tɛɹən meɪz ə ðə fɹɪn kɑɹpət. ɛniwʌn u lɔs ðət mʌtʃ blʌd hæd tə bi dɛd. tu ʌðɝ mɛn leɪ spɹɔld ɑn ðə flɔɹ, wʌn wɪð dɛθ-ɡleɪzd aɪz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ, ði ʌðɝ ɑn ɪz saɪd, ən aɪvɝi naɪf hɪl stɪkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ɪz ɹɪbz wɛɹ ðə bleɪd hæd ʃʊɹli ɹitʃt ɪz hɑɹt. ʃɔɹt, peɪl-skɪn kɛɹhinɪn, boʊθ wɔɹ ðə lɪvɝi ʌv pæləs sɝvəns, bʌɾ ə sɝvənt nɛvɝ kæɹid ðə lɔŋ, wʊɾən-hændəld dæɡɝ ðət leɪ bɪsaɪɾ itʃ kɔɹps. eɪ haʊs tæbɔɹwɪn mæn, hɪz fʊt dʒɹɔn bæk tə kɪk wʌn ə ðə kɔɹpsəz, hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɑn siɪŋ ðə tu sɪstɝz, ðən plæntəɾ ɪz but hɑɹɾ ɪn ðə dɛd mænz ɹɪbz ɛniweɪ. klɪɹli, pɹɑpɝ dɪkɔɹəm leɪ fɑɹ fɹəm ɛniwʌnz maɪn ət ðə moʊmənt.

Dobraine did not appear to be breathing, and there were bloodstained gashes in the chest of his coat, with its thin stripes of color that marched down to his knees. Beside the litter, a dark blot larger than a man's body marred the green-and-yellow Tairen maze of the fringed carpet. Anyone who lost that much blood had to be dead. Two other men lay sprawled on the floor, one with death-glazed eyes glaring at the ceiling, the other on his side, an ivory knife hilt sticking up from his ribs where the blade had surely reached his heart. Short, pale-skinned Cairhienin, both wore the Livery of palace servants, but a servant never carried the long, wooden-handled dagger that lay beside each corpse. A House Taborwin man, his foot drawn back to kick one of the corpses, hesitated on seeing the two sisters, then planted his boot hard in the dead man's ribs anyway. Clearly, proper decorum lay far from anyone's mind at the moment.

"muv ðət klɔθ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ," sæʃəl toʊl ðə mɛn baɪ ðə lɪɾɝ. "sæmɪtsu, si wɛðɝ jə kən stɪl hɛlp lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn."

"Move that cloth out of the way," Sashalle told the men by the litter. "Samitsu, see whether you can still help Lord Dobraine."

wʌtɛvɝ ʃi bɪlivd, ɪnstɪŋk hæd muv sæmɪtsu təwɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn, bʌt ðət kəmænd-ɪt wɑz dɛflaɪ ə kəmænd! -pʊɾ ə stʌɾɝ ɪn əɹ stɛp. ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ, ʃi kɛp muvɪŋ, ən nɛl kɛɹfəli bɪsaɪd ðə lɪɾɝ, ɑn ðə saɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɪl dæmp blɑt, tə pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn dɑbɹeɪnz blʌd-soʊk hɛd. ʃi nɛvɝ maɪndəd ɡɛɾɪŋ blʌɾ ɑn əɹ hænz, bʌt blʌdsteɪnz wɝ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə sɪlk ənlɛs jə tʃænəld, ən ʃi stɪl fɛlt ə pæŋ ʌv ɡɪlt ət ðə weɪst wən ʃi juz ðə paʊɝ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ soʊ məndeɪn.

Whatever she believed, instinct had moved Samitsu toward Dobraine, but that command-it was deafly a command! -put a stutter in her step. Gritting her teeth, she kept moving, and knelt carefully beside the litter, on the side away from the still damp blot, to put her hands on Dobraine's blood-soaked head. She never minded getting blood on her hands, but bloodstains were impossible to get out of silk unless you channeled, and she still felt a pang of guilt at the waste when she used the Power for something so mundane.

ðə nɛsəsɛɹi wivz wɝ sɛkənd neɪtʃɝ tə hɝ, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət ʃi ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs ən dɛlv ðə kɛɹhinɪn lɔɹd wɪθaʊɾ ə θɔt. ən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ɪnstɪŋk hæd meɪɾ əɹ ɡoʊ əhɛd, ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn sɝɾən ðəɹ wɝ θɹi kɔɹpsəz ɪn ðə ɹum, jɛt laɪf stɪl flɪkɝɾ ɪn dɑbɹeɪn. ə taɪni ɡʌɾɝɪŋ fleɪm ðət ðə ʃɑk ə hilɪŋ maɪt wɛl ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃ. ðə ʃɑk ə ðə hilɪŋ ʃi nu. hɝ aɪz sɝtʃt aʊt ðə peɪl-hɛɹɾ æʃəmən. hi wɑz kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd wʌn ə ðə dɛd sɝvəns, kɑmli sɝtʃɪŋ ðə mæn, əblɪviəs tə ðə ʃɑk stɛɹz ə ðə lɪvɪŋ sɝvəns. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən sʌɾənli noʊɾəst lɔɪəl, stændɪŋ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ən ɡɑɡəld əz ɪf i hæd lɛpt aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ. wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ən ə ɡɹɪm ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz bɹɔd feɪs, ði oʊɡiɝ lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi wɝ stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd.

The necessary weaves were second nature to her, so much so that she embraced the Source and delved the Cairhienin lord without a thought. And blinked in surprise. Instinct had made her go ahead, though she had been certain there were three corpses in the room, yet life still flickered in Dobraine. A tiny guttering flame that the shock of Healing might well extinguish. The shock of the Healing she knew. Her eyes searched out the pale-haired Asha'man. He was crouched beside one of the dead servants, calmly searching the man, oblivious to the shocked stares of the living servants. One of the women suddenly noticed Loial, standing just inside the door, and goggled as if he had leapt out of thin air. With his arms folded across his chest and a grim expression on his broad face, the Ogier looked as though he were standing guard.

"kɑɹldɪn, dʒju noʊ ðə kaɪndə hilɪŋ ðət deɪmɝ flɪn juzd," sæmɪtsu æskt. "ðə kaɪn ðət juzɪz ɔl ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz?"

"Karldin, do you know the kind of Healing that Damer Flinn used," Samitsu asked. "The kind that uses all of the Five Powers?"

hi pɔz fəɹ ə moʊmənt, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət hɝ. "flɪn! aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ wʌt jəɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, aɪ doʊn əv mʌtʃ tælən fəɹ hilɪŋ ɛniweɪ." aɪɪŋ dɑbɹeɪn, hi æɾəd, "hi lʊks dɛd tə mi, bʌɾ aɪ hoʊp jə kən seɪv hɪm. hi wɑz ət ðə wɛlz." ən i bɛn bæk tə ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə dɛd sɝvəns koʊt.

He paused for a moment, frowning at her. "Flinn! I don't even know what you're talking about, I don't have much Talent for Healing anyway." Eyeing Dobraine, he added, "He looks dead to me, but I hope you can save him. He was at the Wells." And he bent back to rummaging through the dead servant's coat.

sæmɪtsu lɪkt əɹ lɪps. ðə θɹɪl ə biɪŋ fɪld wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ ɔlweɪz sim dɪmɪnɪʃt tə hɝ, ɪn sɪtʃueɪʃənz laɪk ðɪs. sɪtʃueɪʃənz wən ɔl ə hɝ pɑsəbəl tʃɔɪsəz wɝ bæd. kɛɹfəli, ʃi ɡæðɝd floʊz ʌv ɛɹ, spɪɹəɾ ən wɔɾɝ, wivɪŋ əm dʒʌst soʊ, ðə beɪsɪk wiv ə hilɪŋ ðəɾ ɛvɹi sɪstɝ nu. noʊ wʌn ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi hæd ðə tælən fəɹ hilɪŋ əz stʃɹɔŋli əz ʃi, ən moʊst sɪstɝz wɝ lɪməɾəd ɪn wʌt ðeɪ kəd hil, səm tə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən bɹuzəz. baɪ hɝsɛlf, ʃi kəd hil ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz ə lɪŋk sɝkəl. moʊst sɪstɝz kəd nɑt ɹɛɡjəleɪt ðə wiv tə ɛni dɪɡɹi əɾ ɔl; moʊs dɪd nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə lɝn. ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. oʊ, ʃi kəd nɑt hil wʌn pɝtɪkjəlɝ θɪŋ ən liv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls əz ɪt wɑz, ðə weɪ deɪmɝ kʊd; wʌt ʃi dɪd wəɾ əfɛkt ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm ðə stæb wunz tə ðə stʌf noʊz dɑbɹeɪn wɑz ɔlsoʊ sʌfɝɪŋ fɹʌm. dɛlvɪŋ hæd toʊld əɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɾ eɪl hɪm. bʌt ʃi kəd wɑʃ əweɪ ðə wɝst ɪnʒɝiz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn, əɹ hil soʊ huɛvɝ ʃi hild əpɪɹd tə hæv spɛn deɪz ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ ɑn əɹ oʊn, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin. itʃ tʊk noʊ lɛs ə hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd ɹikwaɪɝ lɛs fɹəm ðə peɪʃənt. ðə smɔlɝ ði əmaʊn ə tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə bɑɾi, ðə smɔlɝ ði əmaʊn ə ðə bɑɾiz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪt dʒɹeɪnd. oʊnli, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ɡæʃ ɪn ɪz skælp, dɑbɹeɪnz wunz wɝ ɔl sɪɹiəs, fɔɹ dip pʌŋktʃɝz ɪn ɪz lʌŋz, tu ʌv əm ɡæʃɪŋ ðə hɑɹɾ əz wɛl. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs hilɪŋ wəd kɪl ɪm bɪfɔɹ ɪz wunz fɪnɪʃt kloʊzɪŋ, waɪl ðə wikəst wəd ɹɪvaɪv ɪm lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaʊn ɪn ɪz oʊn blʌd. ʃi hæd tə tʃuz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ən hoʊp ðət ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt.

Samitsu licked her lips. The thrill of being filled with Saidar always seemed diminished to her, in situations like this. Situations when all of her possible choices were bad. Carefully, she gathered flows of Air, Spirit and Water, weaving them just so, the basic weave of Healing that every sister knew. No one in living memory had the Talent for Healing as strongly as she, and most sisters were limited in what they could Heal, some to little more than bruises. By herself, she could Heal almost as well as a linked circle. Most sisters could not regulate the weave to any degree at all; most did not even try to learn. She had been able to from the start. Oh, she could not Heal one particular thing and leave everything else as it was, the way Damer could; what she did would affect everything from the stab wounds to the stuffed nose Dobraine was also suffering from. Delving had told her everything that ailed him. But she could wash away the worst injuries as if they had never been, or Heal so whoever she Healed appeared to have spent days recovering on her own, or anything in between. Each took no less of her strength, but they did require less from the patient. The smaller the amount of change in the body, the smaller the amount of the body's strength it drained. Only, except for the gash in his scalp, Dobraine's wounds were all serious, four deep punctures in his lungs, two of them gashing the heart as well. The strongest Healing would kill him before his wounds finished closing, while the weakest would revive him long enough to drown in his own blood. She had to choose somewhere in the middle and hope that she was right.

aɪm ðə bɛs ðəɾ ɛvɝ əz bɪn, ʃi θɔt ɡɹɪmli. kædzueɪn hæd toʊld əɹ ðæt, aɪm ðə bɛst.

I am the best that ever has been, she thought grimly. Cadsuane had told her that, I am the best.

ɔltɝɪŋ ðə wiv slaɪtli, ʃi lɛɾ ɪt sɪŋk ɪndə ðə moʊʃənləs mæn, səm ə ðə sɝvəns kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn əlɑɹm əz dɑbɹeɪnz bɑɾi kənvʌlsd. hi hæf sæɾ ʌp, dip-sɛɾ aɪz oʊpənɪŋ waɪd, lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌt saʊndəɾ ɔl tu mʌtʃ laɪk ə lɔŋ dɛθ ɹæɾəl tə ɹʌʃ aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ. ðən ɪz aɪz ɹoʊl bæk ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən i slɪp fɹəm əɹ ɡɹæsp, θəɾɪŋ bæk daʊn ɑntu ðə lɪɾɝ. heɪstəli, ʃi ɹiədʒʌstɪd ðə wiv ən dɛlvd ɪm əɡɛn, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ. hi lɪvd. baɪ ə hɛɹ, ən soʊ wik i maɪt jɛt daɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðoʊz stæbz ðət kɪl hɪm, ɪksɛpt ɪndɝɛkli. ivən θɹu daɪ dʒɹaɪɪŋ blʌd ðət mæɾɪd ɪz hɛɹ, ʃeɪvən əweɪ fɹəm ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ʃi kəd si ðə pʌkɝd pɪŋk laɪn ʌv ə fɹɛʃ, ɹɛndɝ skɑɹ əkɹɔs ɪz skælp. hi wəɾ əv ðə seɪm bɪniθ ɪz koʊt, ən i maɪt bi tʃɹʌbəl baɪ ʃɔɹtnəs ə bɹɛθ wən i ɪɡzɝɾɪd hɪmsɛlf, ɪf i pʊl θɹu, jɛt fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, hi dɪd lɪv, ən ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ðə mæɾɝ ə hu hæd wɑntəɾ ɪm dɛd, ən waɪ.

Altering the weave slightly, she let it sink into the motionless man, Some of the servants cried out in alarm as Dobraine's body convulsed. He half sat up, deep-set eyes opening wide, long enough for what sounded all too much like a long death rattle to rush out of his mouth. Then his eyes rolled back in his head, and he slipped from her grasp, thudding back down onto the litter. Hastily, she readjusted the weave and delved him again, holding her breath. He lived. By a hair, and so weak he might yet die, but it would not be those stabs that killed him, except indirectly. Even through die drying blood that matted his hair, shaven away from his forehead, she could see the puckered pink line of a fresh, render scar across his scalp. He would have the same beneath his coat, and he might be troubled by shortness of breath when he exerted himself, if he pulled through, yet for the moment, he did live, and that was all that mattered. For the moment. There was still the matter of who had wanted him dead, and why.

ɹilisɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ʃi stʊɾ ənstɛɾəli. seɪaɪdɑɹ dʒɹeɪnɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ ɔlweɪz meɪɾ əɹ fil taɪɝd.

Releasing the Power, she stood unsteadily. Saidar draining out of her always made her feel tired.

wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn, ɡeɪpɪŋ, hɛzɪɾəntli hændəɾ əɹ ðə klɔθ i hæd bɪn gɑnə leɪ ɑn ɪz lɔɹdz feɪs, ən ʃi juzd ɪt tə waɪp əɹ hænz. "teɪk ɪm tə hɪz bɛd "ʃi sɛd. "ɡɛɾ əz mʌtʃ maɪl hʌni-wɔɾɝ daʊn ɪm əz jə kæn. hi nidz tə ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ kwɪkli. ən faɪn ə waɪz wʊmən ... ə ɹiɾɝ, jɛs, ə ɹiɾɝ. hɪl nid hɝ, tu." hi wɑz aʊɾ ə hɝ hænz, naʊ, ən ɝbz maɪt hɛlp. ət list, ðeɪ wɝ ənlaɪkli tə hɑɹm, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə ɹiɾɝ, ən ət wɝs ðə wʊmən wəd meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ ɡeɪv ɪm ɪnʌf hʌni-wɔɾɝ ən nɑt tu mʌtʃ.

One of the serving men, gaping, hesitantly handed her the cloth he had been going to lay on his lord's face, and she used it to wipe her hands. "Take him to his bed "she said. "Get as much mild honey-water down him as you can. He needs to gain strength quickly. And find a Wise Woman ... a Reader, Yes, a Reader. He will need her, too." He was out of her hands, now, and herbs might help. At least, they were unlikely to harm, coming from a Reader, and at worst the woman would make sure they gave him enough honey-water and not too much.

wɪð mʌtʃ boʊɪŋ ən mɛni mɝmɝz ə θæŋks, fɔɹ ə ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn tʊk ʌp ðə lɪɾɝ ən kæɹid dɑbɹeɪn dipɝ ɪndə ði əpɑɹtməns. moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns fɑloʊd hɝidli, wɛɹɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃənz ə ɹɪlif, ən ðə ɹɛs dæʃt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. ən ɪnstən leɪɾɝ, ɡlæd ʃaʊts ən tʃɪɹz bɹoʊk aʊt, ən ʃi hɝɾ əɹ neɪm nɪɹli əz ɔfən əz dɑbɹeɪnz. vɛɹi ɡɹæɾəfaɪɪŋ. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ ɪf sæʃəl hæd nɑt smaɪld ən ɡɪvən əɹ ən əpɹuvɪŋ nɑd. əpɹuvɪŋ! ən waɪ nɑɾ ə pæɾ ɑn ðə hɛd, waɪl ʃi wɑz əbaʊɾ ɪt?

With much bowing and many murmurs of thanks, four of the serving men took up the litter and carried Dobraine deeper into the apartments. Most of the other servants followed hurriedly, wearing expressions of relief, and the rest dashed out into the corridor. An instant later, glad shouts and cheers broke out, and she heard her name nearly as often as Dobraine's. Very gratifying. It would have been more satisfying if Sashalle had not smiled and given her an approving nod. Approving! And why not a pat on the head, while she was about it?

kɑɹldɪn hæd peɪd noʊ maɪn əɾ ɔl tə daɪ hilɪŋ, ɪnsəfɑɹ əz sæmɪtsu hæd noʊɾəst. fɪnɪʃɪŋ ɪz sɝtʃ ə ðə sɛkən kɔɹps, hi ɹoʊz ən kɹɔs ðə ɹum tə lɔɪəl, ətɛmptɪŋ tə ʃoʊ ði oʊɡiɝ sʌmθɪŋ, ʃildɪd baɪ hɪz bɑɾi, wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊɾəs. lɔɪəl plʌkt ɪt-ə ʃiɾ ə kɹim-kʌlɝd peɪpɝ, kɹis fɹəm foʊldɪŋ-aʊɾ ə ði æʃəmənz hæn ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs oʊpən aʊɾ ɪn ɪz θɪk ɹɪŋɝz, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ kɑɹldɪnz skaʊl "bʌt ðɪs meɪks noʊ sɛns," ði oʊɡiɝ mʌɾɝd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əz i ɹɛd. "noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl. ənlɛs-!" hi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli, lɔŋ ɪɹz flɪkɝɪŋ, ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə tɛns lʊk wɪð ðə peɪl-hɛɹd fɛloʊ, hu ɡeɪv ə kɝt nɑd. "oʊ, ðɪs ɪz vɛɹi bæd," lɔɪəl, sɛd. "ɪf ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ðən tu, kɑɹldɪn, ɪf ðeɪ faʊnd- !" hi tʃoʊkt ɔf ɪz wɝdz əɡɛn əɾ ə fɹæntɪk hɛdʃeɪk fɹəm ðə jʌŋ mæn.

Karldin had paid no mind at all to die Healing, insofar as Samitsu had noticed. Finishing his search of the second corpse, he rose and crossed the room to Loial, attempting to show the Ogier something, shielded by his body, without letting the Aes Sedai notice. Loial plucked it-a sheet of cream-colored paper, creased from folding-out of the Asha'man's hand and held it up in front of his face opened out in his thick ringers, ignoring Karldin's scowl "But this makes no sense," the Ogier muttered, frowning as he read. "No sense at all. Unless-!" He cut off abruptly, long ears flickering, and exchanged a tense look with the pale-haired fellow, who gave a curt nod. "Oh, this is very bad," Loial, said. "If there were more than two, Karldin, if they found- !" He choked off his words again at a frantic headshake from the young man.

"aɪ wɪl si ðæt, pliz," sæʃəl sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ hænd, ən pliz əɹ noʊ pliz, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹɪkwɛst. kɑɹldɪn ətɛmptəd tə snætʃ ðə peɪpɝ fɹəm lɔɪəl ɛs hænd-bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ kɑmli hændəɾ ɪt tə sæʃəl u ɪnspɛktɪɾ ɪt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni tʃeɪnʒ ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən, ðən hændəɾ ɪt tə sæmɪtsu. ɪt wɑz θɪk peɪpɝ, smuð ən ɪkspɛnsɪv, ən nu lʊkɪŋ. sæmɪtsu hæd tə kəntʃɹoʊl əɹ aɪbɹaʊz' dɪzaɪɝ tə klaɪm əz ʃi ɹɛd.

"I will see that, please," Sashalle said, holding out her hand, and please or no please, it was not a request. Karldin attempted to snatch the paper from Loial s hand-but the Ogier calmly handed it to Sashalle who inspected it without any change of expression, then handed it to Samitsu. It was thick paper, smooth and expensive, and new looking. Samitsu had to control her eyebrows' desire to climb as she read.

ət maɪ kəmænd, ðə bɛɹɝz ə ðɪs ɑɹ tə ɹimuv sɝɾən aɪɾəmz, wɪtʃ ðəl noʊ, fɹəm maɪ əpɑɹtməns ən teɪk əm aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn pæləs-meɪk əm pɹaɪvəɾ ə maɪ ɹumz, ɡɪv əm wʌtɛvɝ eɪd ðeɪ ɹikwaɪɝ ən kip saɪlən ɑn ðɪs mæɾɝ, ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ɑn peɪn ə hɪz dɪsplɛʒɝ.

At my command, the bearers of this are to remove certain items, which they will know, from my apartments and take them out of the Sun Palace-Make them private of my rooms, give them whatever aid they require and keep silent on this matter, in the name of the Dragon Reborn and on pain of his displeasure.

dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn ʃi hæd sin dɑbɹeɪnz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔfən ɪnʌf tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə ɹaʊndəd hæn əz hɪz. "ɑbviəsli sʌmwʌn ɛmplɔɪz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd fɔɹdʒɝ," ʃi sɛd, ɝnɪŋ ə kwɪk, kəntɛmptʃuəs ɡlæns fɹəm sæʃəl.

Dobraine Taborwin She had seen Dobraine's writing often enough to recognize the rounded hand as his. "Obviously someone employs a very good forger," she said, earning a quick, contemptuous glance from Sashalle.

"ɪt dɪd sim ənlaɪkli hi ɹoʊɾ ɪt hɪmsɛlf ən wɑz stæbd baɪ hɪz oʊn mɛn ɪn mɪsteɪk," ðə ɹɛd sɛɾ ɪn kʌɾɪŋ toʊnz. hɝ ɡeɪz swʌŋ tə lɔɪəl ən ði æʃəmən. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv faʊnd:" ʃi dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jə ɑɹ əfɹeɪd ðeɪ faʊnd?" kɑɹldɪn stɛɹd bæk əɾ əɹ blænli.

"It did seem unlikely he wrote it himself and was stabbed by his own men in mistake," the Red said in cutting tones. Her gaze swung to Loial and the Asha'man. "What is it they might have found:" she demanded. "What is it you are afraid they found?" Karldin stared back at her blandly.

"aɪ dʒʌs mɛnt wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ," lɔɪəl ænsɝd. "ðeɪ hæd tə bi hɪɹ tə stil sʌmθɪŋ." bʌɾ ɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃt soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ ɔlmoʊs vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ i kəd mæstɝ ðɛm. moʊst oʊɡiɝ meɪd vɛɹi pʊɹ laɪɝz, ət list waɪl jʌŋ.

"I just meant whatever they were looking for," Loial answered. "They had to be here to steal something." But his tufted ears twitched so hard they almost vibrated before he could master them. Most Ogier made very poor liars, at least while young.

sæʃəlz ɹɪŋləts swʌŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd dɪlɪbɝətli. "wʌt jə noʊ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə pɛɹ ə jə ɑɹ nɑt livɪŋ əntɪl aɪ noʊ ɪt, tu."

Sashalle's ringlets swung as she shook her head deliberately. "What you know is important. The pair of you are not leaving until I know it, too."

'æn haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə stɑp ʌs?" ðə vɛɹi kwaɪətnəs ə kɑɹldɪnz wɝdz meɪɾ əm mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs. hi mɛt sæʃəlz ɡeɪz lɛvəli, əz ɪɾ i hæd nɑɾ ə wɝi ɪn ðə wɝld. oʊ, jɛs, vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə wʊlf, nɑɾ ə fɑks.

'And how are you going to stop us?" The very quietness of Karldin's words made them more dangerous. He met Sashalle's gaze levelly, as it he had not a worry in the world. Oh, yes, very much a wolf, not a fox.

"aɪ θɔɾ aɪd nɛvɝ faɪn ju," ɹoʊzɑɹə mɛdʒɹɑnoʊ ənaʊnst, mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðət moʊmən ə pɛɹələs saɪləns stɪl wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɹɛd ɡlʌvz ən fɝ-laɪn kloʊk, wɪð ðə hʊd θɹoʊn bæk tə ɹɪvil ðə kɑɹvd aɪvɝi koʊmz ɪn əɹ blæk hɛɹ. ðəɹ wɝ dæmp pætʃəz ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝz ə ðə kloʊk fɹəm mɛltəd snoʊ. ə tɔl wʊmən, əz bɹaʊn əz ə sʌn-dɑɹk il, ʃi hæd ɡɔn aʊɾ ət fɝs laɪt tə tʃɹaɪ faɪndɪŋ spaɪsəz fəɹ səm sɔɹɾ ə fɪʃ stu fɹəm əɹ neɪɾɪv tɛɹ. ʃi spɛɹɾ oʊnli ðə bɹifɛst ɡlæns fəɹ lɔɪəl ən kɑɹldɪn, ən dɪd nɑt weɪst ə moʊmən ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋ æftɝ dɑbɹeɪn. "ə pɑɹɾi ʌv sɪstɝz əz ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, sæmɪtsu. aɪ ɹoʊd laɪk ə mædwʊmən tə ɡɛt hɪɹ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ kəd bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ət ðɪs moʊmənt.

"I thought I'd never find you," Rosara Medrano announced, marching into that moment of perilous silence still wearing her red gloves and fur-lined cloak, with the hood thrown back to reveal the carved ivory combs in her black hair. There were damp patches on the shoulders of the cloak from melted snow. A tall woman, as brown as a sun-dark Aiel, she had gone out at first light to try finding spices for some sort of fish stew from her native Tear. She spared only the briefest glance for Loial and Karldin, and did not waste a moment inquiring after Dobraine. "A party of sisters has entered the city, Samitsu. I rode like a madwoman to get here ahead of them, but they could be riding in at this moment.

ðəɹ ɑɹ æʃəmən wɪð ðɛm, ən wʌn ə ði æʃəmən ɪz lɑɡən!" kɑɹldɪn bɑɹkt ə ɹʌf læf. ən sʌɾənli sæmɪtsu wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz gɑnə lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ kædzueɪn tə hæv əɹ haɪd.

There are Asha'man with them, and one of the Asha'man is Logain!" Karldin barked a rough laugh. and suddenly Samitsu wondered whether she was going to live long enough for Cadsuane to have her hide.

tʃæptɝ wʌn

CHAPTER 1

taɪm tə bi ɡɔn ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz, ən eɪdʒəz kʌm ən pæs, livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət bɪkʌm lɛdʒənd.

Time to Be Gone The Wheel of Time turns, and Ages come and pass, leaving memories that become legend.

lɛdʒən feɪdz tə mɪθ, ən ivən mɪθ ɪz lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən wən ði eɪdʒ ðət ɡeɪv ɪt bɝθ kʌmz əɡɛn. ɪn wʌn eɪdʒ, kɔl ðə θɝɾ eɪdʒ baɪ sʌm, ən eɪdʒ jɛt tə kʌm, ən eɪdʒ lɔŋ pæst, ə wɪn ɹoʊz ɪn ðə ɹiænən hɪlz. ðə wɪnd wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ niðɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋz nɔɹ ɛndɪŋz tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ə taɪm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

Legend fades to myth, and even myth is long forgotten when the Age that gave it birth comes again. In one Age, called the Third Age by some, an Age yet to come, an Age long past, a wind rose in the Rhiannon Hills. The wind was not the beginning. There are neither beginnings nor endings to the turning of the Wheel of Time. But it was a beginning.

bɔɹn əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹoʊvz ən vɪnjɝdz ðət kʌvɝd mʌtʃ ə ðə ɹʌɡəd hɪlz, ði ɑləv tʃɹiz ɪn ɛvɝɡɹin ɹoʊz, ði ɔɹɾɝd vaɪnz lifləs tɪl spɹɪŋ, ðə koʊld wɪn blu wɛst ən nɔɹθ əkɹɔs ðə pɹɑspɝəs fɑɹmz dɑɾɪŋ ðə læn bɪtwin ðə hɪlz ən ðə ɡɹeɪt hɑɹbɝ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. ðə læn leɪ wɪntɝ fæloʊ stɪl, bʌt mɛn ən wɪmən wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɔɪlɪŋ plaʊʃɛɹz ən tɛndɪŋ hɑɹnəs, pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ ðə plæntɪŋ tə kʌm. ðeɪ peɪd lɪɾəl maɪn tə ðə tʃɹeɪnz ə hɛvəli leɪɾən wæɡənz muvɪŋ ist əlɔŋ ðə dɝt ɹoʊdz kæɹiɪŋ pipəl u wɔɹ ɑd kloʊðz ən spoʊk wɪð ɑɾ æksɛns. mɛni ʌv ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz sim tə bi fɑɹmɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, fəmɪljɝ ɪmpləməns læʃt tə ðɛɹ wæɡən bɑksəz, ən ɪn ðɛɹ wæɡənz ʌnfəmɪljɝ sæplɪŋz wɪð ɹuts bɔld ɪn ɹʌf klɔθ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ ɑn təwɔɹd mɔɹ dɪstən lænd.

Born among the groves and vineyards that covered much of the rugged hills, the olive trees in evergreen rows, the ordered vines leafless till spring, the cold wind blew west and north across the prosperous farms dotting the land between the hills and the great harbor of Ebou Dar. The land lay winter fallow still, but men and women were already oiling plowshares and tending harness, preparing for the planting to come. They paid little mind to the trains of heavily laden wagons moving east along the dirt roads carrying people who wore odd clothes and spoke with odd accents. Many of the strangers seemed to be farmers themselves, familiar implements lashed to their wagon boxes, and in their wagons unfamiliar saplings with roots balled in rough cloth, but they were heading on toward more distant land.

nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð laɪf hɪɹ ən naʊ. ðə sintʃæn hæn leɪ laɪtli ɑn ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt kəntɛst sintʃæn ɹul, ən ðə fɑɹmɝz ə ðə ɹiænən hɪlz hæd sin noʊ tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ðɛɹ laɪvz. fəɹ ðɛm, ɹeɪn əɹ ðə læk ʌv ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə tʃɹu ɹulɝ.

Nothing to do with life here and now. The Seanchan hand lay lightly on those who did not contest Seanchan rule, and the farmers of the Rhiannon Hills had seen no changes in their lives. For them, rain or the lack of it had always been the true ruler.

wɛst ən nɔɹθ ðə wɪn blu, əkɹɔs ðə bɹɔd blu-ɡɹin ɪkspæns ə ðə hɑɹbɝ, wɛɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə hjudʒ ʃɪps sæt ɹɑkɪŋ əɾ æŋkɝ ɑn tʃɑpi swɛlz, səm blʌf-baʊɾ ən ɹɪɡd wɪð ɹɪb seɪlz, ʌðɝz lɔŋ ən ʃɑɹp-pɹaʊd, wɪð mɛn leɪbɝɪŋ tə mætʃ ðɛɹ seɪlz ən ɹɪɡɪŋ tə ðoʊz ə ðə waɪɾɝ vɛsəlz. nɑt nɪɹli soʊ mɛni ʃɪps stɪl floʊɾəd ðəɹ əz hæɾ oʊnli ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ, ðoʊ.

West and north the wind blew, across the broad blue-green expanse of the harbor, where hundreds of huge ships sat rocking at anchor on choppy swells, some bluff-bowed and rigged with ribbed sails, others long and sharp-prowed, with men laboring to match their sails and rigging to those of the wider vessels. Not nearly so many ships still floated there as had only a few days before, though.

mɛni naʊ leɪ ɪn ðə ʃæloʊz, tʃɑɹd ɹɛks hild oʊvɝ ɑn ðɛɹ saɪdz, ən bɝn fɹeɪmz sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn ðə dip ɡɹeɪ mʌd laɪk blækən skɛləɾənz. smɔlɝ kɹæf skɪɾɝd əbaʊt ðə hɑɹbɝ, slæntɪŋ ʌndɝ tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz əɹ kɹɔlɪŋ ɑn ɔɹz laɪk mɛni-lɛɡəd wɔɾɝbəɡz, moʊs kæɹiɪŋ wɝkɝz ən səplaɪz tə ðə ʃɪps ðət stɪl floʊɾəd. ʌðɝ smɔl vɛsəlz ən bɑɹdʒəz ɹoʊd tɛðɝd tə wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi tʃɹitʃɹəŋks ʃɔɹn ə bɹæntʃəz, ɹaɪzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə blu-ɡɹin wɔɾɝ, ən fɹəm ðoʊz mɛn dʌv hoʊldɪŋ stoʊnz tə kæɹi ðɛm daʊn swɪfli tə sʌŋkən ʃɪps bɪloʊ, wɛɹ ðeɪ taɪd ɹoʊps tə wʌtɛvɝ kəd bi hɔld ʌp fəɹ sælvədʒ. sɪks naɪts əɡoʊ dɛθ hæd wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə wɔɾɝ hɪɹ, ðə wʌn paʊɝ kɪlɪŋ mɛn ən wɪmən ən ʃɪps ɪn dɑɹknəs splɪt baɪ sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋz ən hɝtlɪŋ bɔlz ə faɪɝz. naʊ, ðə ɹʌf ɹoʊlɪŋ hɑɹbɝ, fɪld wɪð fjʊɹiəs æktɪvəɾi, simd ət pis baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən, ðə tʃɑp ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp spɹeɪ tə ðə wɪn ðət blu nɔɹθ ən wɛst əkɹɔs ðə maʊθ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪldɑɹ, wɛɹ ɪt waɪɾənd ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝ, nɔɹθ ən wɛst ən ɪnlænd.

Many now lay in the shallows, charred wrecks heeled over on their sides, and burned frames settling in the deep gray mud like blackened skeletons. Smaller craft skittered about the harbor, slanting under triangular sails or crawling on oars like many-legged waterbugs, most carrying workers and supplies to the ships that still floated. Other small vessels and barges rode tethered to what appeared to be treetrunks shorn of branches, rising out of the blue-green water, and from those men dove holding stones to carry them down swiftly to sunken ships below, where they tied ropes to whatever could be hauled up for salvage. Six nights ago death had walked across the water here, the One Power killing men and women and ships in darkness split by silver lightnings and hurtling balls of fires. Now, the rough rolling harbor, filled with furious activity, seemed at peace by comparison, the chop giving up spray to the wind that blew north and west across the mouth of the River Eldar, where it widened into the harbor, north and west and inland.

sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ətɑp ə boʊldɝ kʌvɝd wɪð bɹaʊn mɔs, ɑn ðə ɹid-fɹɪn bæŋk ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, mæt hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛns ðə wɪn ən kɝst saɪlənli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡoʊl tə bi faʊn hɪɹ, noʊ wɪmən əɹ dænsɪŋ, noʊ fʌn. plɛnti ʌv dɪskʌmfɝt, ðoʊ. ɪn ʃɔɹt, ɪt wɑz ðə læst sɔɹɾ ə pleɪs i wəd tʃuz, nɔɹməli. ðə sʌn stʊd bɛɹli ɪts oʊn haɪɾ əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd wɑz peɪl sleɪt ɡɹeɪ, ən θɪk pɝpəl klaʊdz muvɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ðə si θɹɛɾənd ɹeɪn. wɪntɝ hɑɹdli simd wɪntɝ wɪθaʊt snoʊ  hi hæd jɛt tə si ə sɪŋɡəl fleɪk ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ  bʌɾ ə koʊl dæmp mɔɹnɪŋ wɪn ɔf ðə wɔɾɝ kəd sɝv əz wɛl əz snoʊ tə tʃɪl ə mæn tə ðə boʊn. fɔɹ naɪts sɪns i hæd ɹɪɾən aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ɪn ə stɔɹm, jɛɾ ɪz θɹɑbɪŋ hɪp sim tə θɪŋk i wɑz stɪl soʊk tə ðə skɪn ən klɪŋɪŋ tə ə sæɾəl. ðɪs wɑz noʊ wɛðɝ əɹ taɪm ə deɪ fəɹ ə mæn tə bi aʊt baɪ hɪz oʊn tʃɔɪs. hi wɪʃt i hæd θɔt tə bɹɪŋ ə kloʊk. hi wɪʃt i hæd steɪɾ ɪn bɛd.

Sitting cross-legged atop a boulder covered with brown moss, on the reed-fringed bank of the river, Mat hunched his shoulders against the wind and cursed silently. There was no gold to be found here, no women or dancing, no fun. Plenty of discomfort, though. In short, it was the last sort of place he would choose, normally. The sun stood barely its own height above the horizon, the sky overhead was pale slate gray, and thick purple clouds moving in from the sea threatened rain. Winter hardly seemed winter without snow  he had yet to see a single flake in Ebou Dar  but a cold damp morning wind off the water could serve as well as snow to chill a man to the bone. Four nights since he had ridden out of the city in a storm, yet his throbbing hip seemed to think he was still soaked to the skin and clinging to a saddle. This was no weather or time of day for a man to be out by his own choice. He wished he had thought to bring a cloak. He wished he had stayed in bed.

ɹɪpəlz ɪn ðə læn hɪɾ ɛbu dɑɹ, dʒʌst oʊvɝ ə maɪl tə ðə saʊθ, ən hɪɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, əz wɛl, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə tʃɹi əɹ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən skɹʌb bɹʌʃ ɪn saɪt. biɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpən ðɪs weɪ meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ðoʊ æns wɝ kɹɔlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz skɪn. hi ʃəd bi seɪf, ðoʊ. hɪz pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊlən koʊɾ ən kæp wɝ nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðə kloʊðz i wɑz noʊn baɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ɪnstɛɾ ə blæk sɪlk, ə dʒɹæb wʊlən skɑɹf hɪd ðə skɑɹ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, ən ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt wɑz tɝn ʌp tə haɪd ðæt, əz wɛl. nɑɾ ə bɪɾ ə leɪs əɹ ə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. dʌl ɪnʌf fəɹ ə fɑɹmɝ mɪlkɪŋ kaʊz. noʊ wʌn i niɾəd tə əvɔɪd wəd noʊ hɪm tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ hɪm. nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ kloʊs. dʒʌs ðə seɪm, hi tʌɡd ðə kæp ə bɪt loʊɝ.

Ripples in the land hid Ebou Dar, just over a mile to the south, and hid him from the city, as well, but there was not a tree or anything more than scrub brush in sight. Being in the open this way made him feel as though ants were crawling under his skin. He should be safe, though. His plain brown woolen coat and cap were nothing like the clothes he was known by in the city. Instead of black silk, a drab woolen scarf hid the scar around his neck, and the collar of his coat was turned up to hide that, as well. Not a bit of lace or a thread of embroidery. Dull enough for a farmer milking cows. No one he needed to avoid would know him to recognize if they saw him. Not unless they were close. Just the same, he tugged the cap a bit lower.

"ju ɪntɛn tə steɪ aʊt hɪɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, mæt?" noʊlz tæɾɝd dɑɹk blu koʊt hæd sin bɛɾɝ deɪz, bʌt ðən soʊ hæd hi. stupt ən waɪt-hɛɹd, ðə bɹoʊkən-noʊzd oʊl fɛloʊ wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz hilz bɪloʊ ðə boʊldɝ, fɪʃɪŋ ɔf ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk wɪð ə bæmbu poʊl. moʊst ə hɪz tiθ wɝ mɪsɪŋ, ən səmtaɪmz i fɛlt əɾ ə ɡæp wɪð ɪz tʌŋ əz ðoʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ði ɛmpti speɪs. "ɪts koʊld, ɪn keɪs jə hævənt noʊɾəst. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɔlweɪz θɪŋks ɪts wɔɹm ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt wɪntɝ ɪz koʊld ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ivən pleɪsəz ðət meɪk ɛbu dɑɹ fil laɪk ʃaɪnɝ. maɪ boʊnz kɹeɪv ə faɪɝ. əɹ ə blæŋkət, ɛniweɪ. ə mæn kən bi snʌɡ wɪð ə blæŋkət, ɪf hiz aʊɾ ə ðə wɪnd. ɑɹ jə gɑnə də ɛniθɪŋ bʌt stɛɹ daʊnɹɪvɝ?"

"You intend to stay out here much longer, Mat?" Noal's tattered dark blue coat had seen better days, but then so had he. Stooped and white-haired, the broken-nosed old fellow was squatting on his heels below the boulder, fishing off the riverbank with a bamboo pole. Most of his teeth were missing, and sometimes he felt at a gap with his tongue as though surprised to find the empty space. "It's cold, in case you haven't noticed. Everybody always thinks it's warm in Ebou Dar, but winter is cold everywhere, even places that make Ebou Dar feel like Shienar. My bones crave a fire. Or a blanket, anyway. A man can be snug with a blanket, if he's out of the wind. Are you going to do anything but stare downriver?"

wən mæt oʊnli ɡlænst ət hɪm, noʊl ʃɹʌɡd ən wɛn bæk tə piɹɪŋ ət ðə tɑɹd wʊɾən floʊt bɑbɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə spɑɹs ɹidz. naʊ ən ðən i wɝkt wʌn nɑɹl hæn əz ðoʊ hɪz kɹʊkəd fɪŋɡɝz fɛl ðə tʃɪl pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli, bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, ɪt wɑz ɪz oʊn fɔlt. ði oʊl ful hæd ɡɔn weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃæloʊz tə skup ʌp mɪnoʊz fəɹ beɪt wɪð ə bæskət ðət naʊ sæt hæf-səbmɝdʒd ən æŋkɝd baɪ ə smuð stoʊn ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wɔɾɝ. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz kəmpleɪns əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ, noʊl hæd kʌm əlɔŋ tə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɝdʒɪŋ əɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃən. fɹəm θɪŋz i hæd sɛd, ɛvɹiwʌn i kɛɹɾ əbaʊt wɑz lɔŋ jɪɹz dɛd, ən ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt wɑz, hi simd ɔlmoʊs dɛspɹɪt fəɹ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə kʌmpəni. dɛspɹɪt, ɪndid, tə tʃuz mæts kʌmpəni wən i kəd bi faɪv deɪz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ baɪ naʊ. ə mæn kəd kʌvɝ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊn ɪn faɪv deɪz ɪf i hæd ɹizən tə ən ə ɡʊd hɔɹs. mæt hæd θɔɾ ɑn ðət vɛɹi sʌbʒɪkt ɔfən ɪnʌf hɪmsɛlf.

When Mat only glanced at him, Noal shrugged and went back to peering at the tarred wooden float bobbing among the sparse reeds. Now and then he worked one gnarled hand as though his crooked fingers felt the chill particularly, but if so, it was his own fault. The old fool had gone wading in the shallows to scoop up minnows for bait with a basket that now sat half-submerged and anchored by a smooth stone at the edge of the water. Despite his complaints about the weather, Noal had come along to the river without urging or invitation. From things he had said, everyone he cared about was long years dead, and the truth of it was, he seemed almost desperate for any sort of company. Desperate, indeed, to choose Mat's company when he could be five days from Ebou Dar by now. A man could cover a lot of ground in five days if he had reason to and a good horse. Mat had thought on that very subject often enough himself.

ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ði ɪldɑɹ, hæf-hɪɾən baɪ wʌn ə ðə mɑɹʃi aɪlənz ðət dɑɾəd ðə ɹɪvɝ, ə bɹɔd-bimd ɹoʊboʊt bækt ɔɹz, ən wʌn ə ðə kɹu stʊɾ ʌp ən fɪʃt ɪn ðə ɹidz wɪð ə lɔŋ boʊtʊk. ənʌðɝ ɔɹzmən hɛlpt ɪm hiv wʌɾ i hæd kɑɾ ɪndə ðə boʊt. ət ðɪs dɪstəns, ɪt lʊk laɪk ə lɑɹdʒ sæk. mæt wɪnst ən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz aɪz daʊnɹɪvɝ. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl faɪndɪŋ bɑɾiz, ən i wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl. ði ɪnəsən daɪɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ɡɪlti. ən ɪf jə dɪd nʌθɪŋ, ðən oʊnli ði ɪnəsən daɪd. əɹ əz bæɾ əz daɪd. meɪbi wɝs ðæn, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn haʊ jə lʊkt əɾ ɪt.

On the far side of the Eldar, half-hidden by one of the marshy islands that dotted the river, a broad-beamed rowboat backed oars, and one of the crew stood up and fished in the reeds with a long boathook. Another oarsman helped him heave what he had caught into the boat. At this distance, it looked like a large sack. Mat winced and shifted his eyes downriver. They were still finding bodies, and he was responsible. The innocent died along with the guilty. And if you did nothing, then only the innocent died. Or as bad as died. Maybe worse than, depending on how you looked at it.

hi skaʊld ɪɹɪɾəbli. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, hi wɑz tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə blʌɾi fəlɑsəfɝ! teɪkɪŋ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi dʒɹeɪn ɔl ðə dʒɔɪ aʊɾ ə laɪf ən dʒɹaɪɾ ə mæn tə dʌst. wʌɾ i wɑntəd ɹaɪt ðən wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə mʌld waɪn ɪn ə snʌɡ kɑmən ɹum fʊl ə mjuzɪk, ən ə plʌmp, pɹɪɾi sɝvɪŋ meɪɾ ɑn ɪz ni, sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ. vɛɹi fɑɹ. wʌɾ i hæd wɝ ɑbləɡeɪʃənz i kəd nɑt wɔk əweɪ fɹəm ən ə fjutʃɝ i dɪd nɑt fænsi. ðəɹ sim noʊ hɛlp əɾ ɔl ɪn biɪŋ tɑvɝən, nɑɾ ɪf ðɪs wɑz haʊ ðə pæɾɝn ʃeɪpt ɪtsɛlf tə ju. hi stɪl hæɾ ɪz lʌk, ɛniweɪ. ət list, hi wɑz əlaɪv ən nɑt tʃeɪn ɪn ə sɛl. ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, ðət kaʊntəɾ əz lʌk.

He scowled irritably. Blood and ashes, he was turning into a bloody philosopher! Taking responsibility drained all the joy out of life and dried a man to dust. What he wanted right then was a great deal of mulled wine in a snug common room full of music, and a plump, pretty serving maid on his knee, somewhere far from Ebou Dar. Very far. What he had were obligations he could not walk away from and a future he did not fancy. There seemed no help at all in being ta'veren, not if this was how the Pattern shaped itself to you. He still had his luck, anyway. At least, he was alive and not chained in a cell. Under the circumstances, that counted as luck.

fɹəm ɪz pɝtʃ, hi hæɾ ə fɛɹli klɪɹ vju daʊn pæs ðə læs loʊ mɑɹʃi ɹɪvɝ aɪlənz. wɪnd-kɑt spɹeɪ dʒɹɪftəɾ ʌp ðə hɑɹbɝ laɪk bæŋks ə faɪn mɪst, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə haɪd wʌɾ i niɾəd tə si.

From his perch, he had a fairly clear view down past the last low marshy river islands. Wind-caught spray drifted up the harbor like banks of fine mist, but not enough to hide what he needed to see.

hi wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ tə də sʌmz ɪn ɪz hɛd, kaʊntɪŋ ʃɪps əfloʊt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kaʊn ɹɛks. hi kɛp luzɪŋ ɪz pleɪs, ðoʊ, θɪŋkɪŋ i hæd kaʊntəd vɛsəlz twaɪs ən stɑɹɾɪŋ oʊvɝ. ðə si foʊk u hæd bɪn ɹikæptʃɝɾ ɪntʃɹuɾəd ɑn ɪz θɔts, tu. hi hæd hɝd ðət ɡɪbɪts ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ, dɪspleɪd mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd kɔɹpsəz, wɪð plækɝdz lɪstɪŋ 'mɝɾɝ' ən 'ɹɪbɛljən' əz ðɛɹ kɹaɪmz.

He was attempting to do sums in his head, counting ships afloat, trying to count wrecks. He kept losing his place, though, thinking he had counted vessels twice and starting over. The Sea Folk who had been recaptured intruded on his thoughts, too. He had heard that gibbets in the Rahad, across the harbor, displayed more than a hundred corpses, with placards listing 'murder' and 'rebellion' as their crimes.

nɔɹməli, ðə sintʃæn juz ðə hɛdzmənz æks ən ði ɪmpəlɪŋ steɪk, waɪl ðə blʌd ɡɑt ðə stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ kɔɹd, bʌt pɹɑpɝɾi hæd tə sɛɾəl fəɹ biɪŋ hæŋd.

Normally, the Seanchan used the headsman's axe and the impaling stake, while the Blood got the strangling cord, but property had to settle for being hanged.

bɝn mi, aɪ dɪd wʌɾ aɪ kʊd, hi θɔt saʊɝli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus filɪŋ ɡɪlti ðət ðət wɑz ɔl i kəd du. nɑɾ ə bɪɾ ə jus. nʌn! hi hæd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə pipəl u ɪskeɪpt.

Burn me, I did what I could, he thought sourly. There was no use feeling guilty that that was all he could do. Not a bit of use. None! He had to concentrate on the people who escaped.

ði æθɑn maɪɹ u ɡɑɾ əweɪ hæd teɪkən ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ fəɹ ðɛɹ flaɪt, ən waɪl ðeɪ maɪɾ əv siz səm smɔlɝ kɹæft, ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd bɔɹɾ ən oʊvɝwɛlm ɪn ðə naɪt, ðeɪ hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə kæɹi ɔf əz mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ pipəl əz pɑsəbəl. wɪð θaʊzənz ə ðɛm leɪbɝɪŋ əz pɹɪznɝz ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, ðət wʊɾə mɛn bɪɡ ʃɪps, baɪ tʃɔɪs, ən ðət mɛn sintʃæn ɡɹieɪtʃɪps. mɛni ʌv ðə si foʊks oʊn vɛsəlz wɝ lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf, fəɹ sɝɾən, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl hæd bɪn stʃɹɪpt ə ðɛɹ seɪlz ən ɹɪɡɪŋ baɪ ðət taɪm, tə bi fɪɾəd aʊɾ ɪn ðə sintʃæn fæʃən. ɪf i kəd kælkjəleɪt haʊ mɛni ɡɹieɪtʃɪps ɹɪmeɪnd, hi maɪɾ əv səm noʊʃən ə haʊ mɛni æθɑn maɪɹ hæɾ æktʃəli  ɹitʃt fɹiɾəm. fɹiɪŋ ðə si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝz hæd bɪn ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ tə du, ði oʊnli θɪŋ i kəd du, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə hæŋʒɪŋz, hʌnʒɹədz ən hʌnʒɹədz ə bɑɾiz hæd bɪn fɪʃt aʊɾ ə ðə hɑɹbɝ ɪn ðə læs faɪv deɪz, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu haʊ mɛni hæd wɑʃt aʊt tə si wɪð ðə taɪdz. ðə ɡɹeɪvɛdɪɝz leɪbɝd fɹəm sʌnʌp tə sʌndaʊn, ən ðə ɡɹeɪvjɑɹdz wɝ fɪld wɪð wipɪŋ wɪmən ən tʃɪlʒɹən. mɛn, tu. mɔɹ ðən ə fju ʌv ðoʊz dɛd hæd bɪn æθɑn maɪɹ, wɪð noʊ wʌn tə wip waɪl ðeɪ wɝ dʌmpt ɪndə mæs ɡɹeɪvz, ən i wɑntəd səm aɪdiə ʌv ðə nʌmbɝ i hæd seɪv tə bæləns ɪz blik səspɪʃənz ə ðə nʌmbɝ i hæd kɪld.

The Atha'an Miere who got away had taken ships in the harbor for their flight, and while they might have seized some smaller craft, anything they could board and overwhelm in the night, they had intended to carry off as many of their people as possible. With thousands of them laboring as prisoners in the Rahad, that would have meant big ships, by choice, and that meant Seanchan greatships. Many of the Sea Folk's own vessels were large enough, for certain, but they all had been stripped of their sails and rigging by that time, to be fitted out in the Seanchan fashion. If he could calculate how many greatships remained, he might have some notion of how many Atha'an Miere had actually reached freedom. Freeing the Sea Folk Windfinders had been the right thing to do, the only thing he could do, but aside from the hangings, hundreds and hundreds of bodies had been fished out of the harbor in the last five days, and the Light only knew how many had washed out to sea with the tides. The gravediggers labored from sunup to sundown, and the graveyards were filled with weeping women and children. Men, too. More than a few of those dead had been Atha'an Miere, with no one to weep while they were dumped into mass graves, and he wanted some idea of the number he had saved to balance his bleak suspicions of the number he had killed.

ɛstəmeɪɾɪŋ haʊ mɛni ʃɪps hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz wɑz dɪfəkəlt, ðoʊ, kwaɪɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm luzɪŋ ðə kaʊnt. ənlaɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪndfɪndɝz hæd noʊ stʃɹɪktʃɝz əɡɛns juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən, nɑt wən ðə seɪfti ʌv ðɛɹ pipəl wɑz ət steɪk, ən ðeɪ wʊɾə wɑntəd tə hɔl pɝsut bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɪɡæn. noʊ wʌn ɡeɪv tʃeɪs ɪn ə bɝnɪŋ ʃɪp. ðə sintʃæn, wɪð ðɛɹ deɪmeɪn, hæɾ ivən lɛs kəmpʌŋkʃən əɡɛns faɪɾɪŋ bæk. laɪtnɪŋ boʊls lɑsɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹeɪn əz numɝəs əz bleɪdz ʌv ɡɹæs ən bɔlz ə faɪɝ stʃɹikɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ, səm ðə saɪz ə hɔɹsəz, ən ðə hɑɹbɝ simd əfleɪm fɹəm wʌn saɪd tə ði ʌðɝ, tɪl ivən ɪn ə stɔɹm ðə naɪt meɪɾ ɛni ɪluməneɪɾɝz ʃoʊ lʊk stɑɹk.

Estimating how many ships had made it out into the Sea of Storms was difficult, though, quite apart from losing the count. Unlike Aes Sedai, Windfinders had no strictures against using the Power as a weapon, not when the safety of their people was at stake, and they would have wanted to halt pursuit before it began. No one gave chase in a burning ship. The Seanchan, with their damane, had even less compunction against fighting back. Lightning bolts lacing through the rain as numerous as blades of grass and balls of fire streaking across the sky, some the size of horses, and the harbor seemed aflame from one side to the other, till even in a storm the night made any Illuminator's show look stark.

wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ i kəd kaʊn ə dʌzən pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðə tʃɑɹd ɹɪbz ʌv ə ɡɹieɪtʃɪp stʌk ʌp aʊɾ ə ʃæloʊ wɔɾɝ əɹ ə hjudʒ blʌf-baʊd hʌl leɪ ɑn ɪts saɪd wɪð ðə hɑɹbɝ weɪvz lɪkɪŋ əɡɛns ðə tɪltəd dɛk, ən twaɪs əz mɛni wɛɹ ðə laɪnz ə blækən tɪmbɝz wɝ faɪnɝ, ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə si foʊk ɹeɪkɝz. əpɛɹənli ðeɪ hæd dɪslaɪk livɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn vɛsəlz tə pipəl u hæd pʊɾ əm ɪn tʃeɪnz.

Without turning his head he could count a dozen places where the charred ribs of a greatship stuck up out of shallow water or a huge bluff-bowed hull lay on its side with the harbor waves licking against the tilted deck, and twice as many where the lines of blackened timbers were finer, the remains of Sea Folk rakers. Apparently they had disliked leaving their own vessels to people who had put them in chains.

θɹi dʌzən ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən ðət wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌŋkən ɹɛks ðət hæd sælvədʒ boʊts wɝkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛm. pɝhæps ə sifɛɹɝ kəd tɛl ɡɹieɪtʃɪp fɹəm ɹeɪkɝ baɪ ðə tɑps ə mæsts stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ, bʌt ðə tæsk wɑz bɪɑn hɪm.

Three dozen right in front of him, and that without adding in the sunken wrecks that had salvage boats working over them. Perhaps a seafarer could tell greatship from raker by the tops of masts sticking out of the water, but the task was beyond him.

sʌɾənli ən oʊl mɛmɹi tʌɡd ət hɪm, ʌv leɪɾɪŋ ʃɪps fəɹ ən ətæk fɹəm ðə si, ən haʊ mɛni mɛn kəd bi kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə haʊ mʌtʃ speɪs fəɹ haʊ lɔŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪz mɛmɹi, ɹɪli, fɹəm ən eɪntʃənt wɔɹ bɪtwin fɝɡənsiə ən mɔɹinə, jɛɾ ɪt sim hɪz. ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd nɑɾ æktʃəli  lɪvd wʌn ə ðoʊz eɪntʃən bɪts ʌv ʌðɝ mɛnz lɪvz ðət wɝ stʌk ɪn ɪz hɛɾ ɔlweɪz tʊk ɪm ə lɪɾəl baɪ sɝpɹaɪz naʊ, soʊ meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ hɪz, ɪn ə weɪ. ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli ʃɑɹpɝ ðən səm stʃɹɛtʃəz ə hɪz oʊn laɪf. ðə vɛsəlz i ɹɪkɔl hæd bɪn smɔlɝ ðən moʊst ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, jɛt ðə pɹɪnsəpəlz wɝ ðə seɪm.

Suddenly an old memory tugged at him, of lading ships for an attack from the sea, and how many men could be crowded into how much space for how long. It was not his memory, really, from an ancient war between Fergansea and Moreina, yet it seemed his. Realizing that he had not actually lived one of those ancient bits of other men's lives that were stuck in his head always took him a little by surprise now, so maybe they were his, in a way. They were certainly sharper than some stretches of his own life. The vessels he recalled had been smaller than most in the harbor, yet the principles were the same.

"ðeɪ doʊn əv ɪnʌf ʃɪps," hi mʌɾɝd. ðə sintʃæn hæɾ ivən mɔɹ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ðən hæd kʌm hɪɹ, bʌt ðə lɔsəz hɪɹ wɝ səfɪʃən tə meɪk ðə dɪfɝəns.

"They don't have enough ships," he muttered. The Seanchan had even more in Tanchico than had come here, but the losses here were sufficient to make the difference.

"ɪnʌf ʃɪps fəɹ wʌt?" noʊl sɛd. "aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ soʊ mɛni ɪn wʌn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ." ðət wɑz kwaɪɾ ə steɪtmənt, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm hɪm. tə hɪɹ noʊl tɛl ɪt, hi hæd sin ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən nɪɹli ɔlweɪz bɪɡɝ əɹ ɡɹændɝ ðən wʌt wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz noʊz. bæk hoʊm, ðeɪ wʊɾə sɛɾ i kɛp taɪt pɝs-stʃɹɪŋz ɑn ðə tʃɹuθ.

"Enough ships for what?" Noal said. "I never saw so many in one place before." That was quite a statement, coming from him. To hear Noal tell it, he had seen everything, and nearly always bigger or grander than what was in front of his nose. Back home, they would have said he kept tight purse-strings on the truth.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðeɪ doʊn əv ɪnʌf ʃɪps lɛf tə teɪk əm ɔl bæk hoʊm."

Mat shook his head. "They don't have enough ships left to take them all back home."

"wi doʊn əv tə ɡoʊ hoʊm," ə wʊmən dʒɹɔl bɪhaɪn hɪm. "wiv kʌm hoʊm." hi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt dʒʌmp ət ðə slɝd sintʃæn æksɛnt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə nɪɹ θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd u wɑz spikɪŋ.

"We don't have to go home," a woman drawled behind him. "We've come home." He did not quite jump at the slurred Seanchan accent, but it was a near thing before he recognized who was speaking.

ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz skaʊlɪŋ, hɝ aɪz laɪk blu dæɡɝz, bʌt nɑt fəɹ hɪm. ət list, hi θɔt nɑt. ʃi wɑz tɔl ən lin, wɪð ə hɑɹd feɪs ðət wɑz peɪl skɪn dɪspaɪɾ ə laɪf ət si. hɝ ɡɹin dʒɹɛs wɑz bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə tɪŋkɝ, əɹ kloʊs tə ɪt, ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ə mæs ə taɪni jɛloʊ ən waɪt blɑsəmz ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk ən daʊn ðə slivz. ə flaʊɝd skɑɹf taɪd taɪtli ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn hɛld ə lɔŋ blæk wɪɡ ɑn əɹ hɛd, spɪlɪŋ hæfweɪ daʊn əɹ bæk ən oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi heɪɾəd ðə skɑɹf ən ðə dʒɹɛs, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt kwaɪt fɪt, bʌɾ əɹ hænz tʃɛkt ɛvɹi ʌðɝ mɪnət tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə wɪɡ wɑz stʃɹeɪt.

Egeanin was scowling, her eyes like blue daggers, but not for him. At least, he thought not. She was tall and lean, with a hard face that was pale skinned despite a life at sea. Her green dress was bright enough for a Tinker, or close to it, and embroidered with a mass of tiny yellow and white blossoms on the high neck and down the sleeves. A flowered scarf tied tightly under her chin held a long black wig on her head, spilling halfway down her back and over her shoulders. She hated the scarf and the dress, which did not quite fit, but her hands checked every other minute to make sure the wig was straight.

ðət kənsɝn əɹ mɔɹ ðən əɹ kloʊðz, ðoʊ kənsɝn wɑz nɑt nɪɹli ə stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf wɝd.

That concerned her more than her clothes, though concern was not nearly a strong enough word.

ʃi hæɾ oʊnli saɪɾ oʊvɝ kʌɾɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ʃɔɹt, bʌt ʃi ɔlmoʊs hæɾ ə fɪt, ɹɛd-feɪst ən pɑp-aɪd, wən i toʊld əɹ ʃi mʌst ʃeɪv əɹ hɛd kəmplitli. ðə weɪ hɝ hɛɹ hæd bɪn kʌt bɪfɔɹ, ʃeɪvd əbʌv əɹ ɪɹz wɪð oʊnli ə boʊl-laɪk kæp ən ə waɪd ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ teɪl ɪn ðə bæk ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, ʃaʊɾəd ðət ʃi wɑz ə ðə sintʃæn blʌd, ə lɛsɝ noʊbəl. ivən sʌmwʌn u hæd nɛvɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn ə sintʃæn wʊɾə ɹɪmɛmbɝd siɪŋ hɝ. ʃi hæɾ əɡɹid, ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌɾ æftɝwɝdz ʃi wɑz kloʊs tə hɪstɛɹɪkəl əntɪl ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə kʌvɝ əɹ skælp. nɑt fəɹ ðə ɹizənz moʊst wɪmən wʊɾə ɡɔn oʊvɝ ðə mun, ðoʊ. noʊ, əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, oʊnli ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli ʃeɪv ðɛɹ hɛdz. mɛn u wɛn bɔl bɪɡæn wɛɹɪŋ wɪɡz əz sun əz ðɛɹ hɛɹ stɑɹɾəd fɔlɪŋ aʊt tə ɛni noʊɾəsəbəl dɪɡɹi. ɛdʒiənɪn wʊɾə daɪd bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn θɪŋk ʃi wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bɪlɔŋ tə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ivən pipəl u wəd nɛvɝ əv hæd ðə θɔɾ ɪn ðɛɹ lɪvz. wɛl, ðət sɔɹɾ ə pɹitɛns dɪd kæɹi ə dɛθ pɛnəlti əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, bʌɾ i wəd nɛvɝ əv bɪlivd ʃi wəd ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊɾ ɪt soʊ. wʌt wɑz wʌn mɔɹ dɛθ pɛnəlti wən jəɹ nɛk wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi biɪŋ stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ ði æks? ðə stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ kɔɹd, ɪn əɹ keɪs. ðə nus wəd bi fəɹ hɪm.

She had only sighed over cutting her long fingernails short, but she almost had a fit, red-faced and pop-eyed, when he told her she must shave her head completely. The way her hair had been cut before, shaved above her ears with only a bowl-like cap and a wide shoulder-length tail in the back remaining, shouted that she was of the Seanchan Blood, a lesser noble. Even someone who had never laid eyes on a Seanchan would have remembered seeing her. She had agreed, reluctantly, but afterwards she was close to hysterical until she was able to cover her scalp. Not for the reasons most women would have gone over the moon, though. No, among the Seanchan, only the Imperial family shaved their heads. Men who went bald began wearing wigs as soon as their hair started falling out to any noticeable degree. Egeanin would have died before letting anyone think she was pretending to belong to the Imperial family, even people who would never have had the thought in their lives. Well, that sort of pretense did carry a death penalty among the Seanchan, but he would never have believed she would go on about it so. What was one more death penalty when your neck was already being stretched for the axe? The strangling cord, in her case. The noose would be for him.

slɪpɪŋ ðə hæf-dʒɹɔn naɪf bæk ʌp ɪz lɛf sliv, hi slɪd daʊn fɹəm ðə boʊldɝ. hi lændəd pʊɹli ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl, bɛɹli haɪɾɪŋ ə wɪns ət ðə stæbɪŋ dʒɑɹ tə hɪz hɪp. hi dɪd haɪɾ ɪt, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz ə noʊbəlwʊmən ən ə ʃɪp kæptən, ən ʃi meɪɾ ɪnʌf tʃɹaɪz ət teɪkɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ wɪθaʊɾ ɪm ʃoʊɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ wiknəs tə ɡɪv əɹ ən oʊpənɪŋ ðən i hæd tə. ʃi hæd kʌm tə hɪm fəɹ hɛlp, nɑt ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹaʊnd, bʌt ðət bʌɾɝd noʊ bɹɛd wɪð hɝ. linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə boʊldɝ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd, hi pɹitɛndəɾ i wɑz laʊnʒɪŋ, aɪdli kɪkɪŋ ət tʌfs ə dɛd ɡɹæs tə wɝk ðə peɪn aʊt. ðət wɑz ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə pʊt swɛɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld wɪnd. fliɪŋ ɪn ðət stɔɹm hæd kɑst ɪm ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ɪz hɪp, ən i hæd nɑt meɪɾ ɪɾ ʌp jɛt.

Slipping the half-drawn knife back up his left sleeve, he slid down from the boulder. He landed poorly and almost fell, barely hiding a wince at the stabbing jar to his hip. He did hide it, though. She was a noblewoman and a ship captain, and she made enough tries at taking charge without him showing any more weakness to give her an opening than he had to. She had come to him for help, not the other way round, but that buttered no bread with her. Leaning against the boulder with his arms folded, he pretended he was lounging, idly kicking at tufts of dead grass to work the pain out. That was sharp enough to put sweat on his forehead despite the cold wind. Fleeing in that storm had cost him ground with his hip, and he had not made it up yet.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk?" hi æsk hɝ. noʊ pɔɪn ɪn mɛnʃənɪŋ ðə læk ə ʃɪps əɡɛn.

"Are you sure about the Sea Folk?" he asked her. No point in mentioning the lack of ships again.

tu mɛni sintʃæn sɛtlɝz hæd spɹɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ ɛniweɪ, ən əpɛɹənli ivən mɔɹ fɹəm tæntʃəkoʊ. haʊɛvɝ mɛni ʃɪps ðeɪ hæd, noʊ paʊɝ ɑn ɝθ wəɾ ɛvɝ ɹuɾ ɔl ðə sintʃæn aʊt, naʊ.

Too many Seanchan settlers had spread out from Ebou Dar anyway, and apparently even more from Tanchico. However many ships they had, no power on earth would ever root all the Seanchan out, now.

ɹitʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə wɪɡ əɡɛn, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ əɹ ʃɔɹt fɪŋɡɝneɪlz, ən ɪnstɛd tʌkt əɹ hænz ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹmz. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɛm?" ʃi nu hi hæd bɪn bɪhaɪn ðə wɪndfɪndɝz'

Reaching toward the wig again, she hesitated, frowning at her short fingernails, and instead tucked her hands under her arms. "What about them?" She knew he had been behind the Windfinders'

bɹeɪk fəɹ fɹiɾəm, bʌt niðɝ ə ðɛm hæd mɛnʃən ɪt spəsɪfɪkli. ʃi ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ði æθɑn maɪɹ. kwaɪɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ɔl ðə sʌŋkən ʃɪps ən dɛd, fɹiɪŋ deɪmeɪn wɑz ənʌðɝ dɛθ pɛnəlti tʃɑɹdʒ, ən dɪsɡʌstɪŋ bɪsaɪdz, ɪn ðə sintʃæn vju, əz bæɾ əz ɹeɪp əɹ məlɛstɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən.

break for freedom, but neither of them had mentioned it specifically. She always tried to avoid talking about the Atha'an Miere. Quite aside from all the sunken ships and dead, freeing damane was another death penalty charge, and disgusting besides, in the Seanchan view, as bad as rape or molesting children.

ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd hɛlp fɹi səm deɪmeɪn hɝsɛlf, ðoʊ tə hɝ weɪ ʌv lʊkɪŋ, ðət wɑz əmʌŋ ðə list ə hɝ kɹaɪmz. stɪl, ʃi əvɔɪɾəd ðət tɑpɪk, tu. ðəɹ wɝ kwaɪɾ ə fju sʌbʒɪkts ʃi hɛl saɪlən ɑn.

Of course, she had helped free some damane herself, though to her way of looking, that was among the least of her crimes. Still, she avoided that topic, too. There were quite a few subjects she held silent on.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən əbaʊt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz u wɝ kɑt? aɪv hɝd tɔk əbaʊt kʌɾɪŋ ɔf hænz, əɹ fit." mæt swɑloʊɾ ə saʊɝ teɪst. hi hæd sin mɛn daɪ, hæd kɪl mɛn wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz.

"Are you certain about the Windfinders who were caught? I've heard talk about cutting off hands, or feet." Mat swallowed a sour taste. He had seen men die, had killed men with his own hands.

ðə laɪt sɛn ɪm mɝsi, hi hæd kɪld ə wʊmən, wʌns! nɑɾ ivən ðə dɑɹkəst ə ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz bɝn soʊ hɑɾ əz ðæt, ən ə fju ʌv ðoʊz wɝ dɑɹk ɪnʌf tə nid dʒɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn waɪn wən ðeɪ floʊɾəd tə ðə sɝfəs. bʌt ðə θɔɾ ə dɪlɪbɝətli kʌɾɪŋ ɔf sʌmbɑɾiz hænz kɝɾəld ɪz stʌmək.

The Light send him mercy, he had killed a woman, once! Not even the darkest of those other men's memories burned so hot as that, and a few of those were dark enough to need drowning in wine when they floated to the surface. But the thought of deliberately cutting off somebody's hands curdled his stomach.

ɛdʒiənɪnz hɛd dʒɝkt, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔt ʃi wəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɪz kwɛstʃən. "tɔk fɹəm ɹɛnə, əl weɪdʒɝ," ʃi sɛd, wɪð ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ. "sʌm sʌldəm tɔk əbaʊt ðət nɑnsɛns tə fɹaɪɾən ɹɪkælsɪtʃɹən deɪmeɪn wən ðəɹ nu-liʃt, bʌt noʊbɑdiz dʌn ɪɾ ɪn, oʊ, sɪks əɹ sɛvən hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. nɑt mɛni, ɛniweɪ, ən pipəl u kæn kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛɹ pɹɑpɝɾi wɪθaʊtmjuɾəleɪʃənɑɹ siməsiv tə stɑɹt." hɝ maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn loʊθɪŋ, ðoʊ wɛðɝ fəɹ mjuɾəleɪʃən əɹ siməsiv wɑz ənklɪɹ.

Egeanin's head jerked, and for a moment he thought she would ignore his question. "Talk from Renna, I'll wager," she said, with a dismissive gesture. "Some sul'dam talk about that nonsense to frighten recalcitrant damane when they're new-leashed, but nobody's done it in, oh, six or seven hundred years. Not many, anyway, and people who can't control their property without...mutilation...are sei'mosiev to start." Her mouth twisted in loathing, though whether for mutilation or sei'mosiev was unclear.

"ʃeɪmd əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ də ɪt," hi snæpt. siməsiv wɛn bɪɑn biɪŋ ʃeɪmd, tə ə sintʃæn, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u dɪlɪbɝətli kʌɾ ɔf ə wʊmənz hæn kəd bi hjumɪlieɪɾɪd ɪnʌf tə kɪl ðɛmsɛlvz. "ɪz sjuɹɔθ wʌn ə ðət 'nɑt mɛni?'"

"Shamed or not, they do it," he snapped. Sei'mosiev went beyond being shamed, to a Seanchan, but he doubted that anyone who deliberately cut off a woman's hand could be humiliated enough to kill themselves. "Is Suroth one of that 'not many?'"

ðə sintʃæn wʊmən ɡlɛɹd tə mætʃ ɪz ən plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð əɹ fiɾ əstʃɹaɪɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ɑn ðə dɛk ʌv ə ʃɪp ən əbaʊt tə bɪɹeɪɾ ə fʌmbəl-wɪɾɪd seɪlɝ. "ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ dʌzn oʊn ðiz deɪmeɪn, jə lʌmp-bɹeɪn fɑɹmɝ! ðəɹ pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. sjuɹɔθ maɪɾ əz wɛl slɪɾ əɹ oʊn ɹɪsts stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ əz ɔɹɾɝ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðət fəɹ ɪmpɪɹiəl deɪmeɪn. ðæts ivən ɪf ʃi wʊd; aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə hɝ mɪstʃɹiɾɪŋ əɹ oʊn. əl tʃɹaɪ tə pʊt ðɪs ɪn tɝmz jə kən ʌndɝstænd. ɪf jəɹ dɔɡ ɹʌnz əweɪ, jə doʊn meɪm ɪt. jə swɪtʃ ðə dɔɡ soʊ ɪt noʊz nɑt tə də ðəɾ əɡɛn, ən jə pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɪn ðə kɛnəl. bɪsaɪdz, deɪmeɪn ɑɹ dʒʌs tu "

The Seanchan woman glared to match his and planted her fists on her hips, leaning forward with her feet astride as though she were on the deck of a ship and about to berate a fumble-witted sailor. "The High Lady Suroth doesn't own these damane, you lump-brained farmer! They're property of the Empress, may she live forever. Suroth might as well slit her own wrists straightaway as order something like that for Imperial damane. That's even if she would; I've never heard of her mistreating her own. I'll try to put this in terms you can understand. If your dog runs away, you don't maim it. You switch the dog so it knows not to do that again, and you put it back in the kennel. Besides, damane are just too "

"tu væljəbəl," mæt fɪnɪʃt fəɹ əɹ dʒɹɪli. hi hæd hɝd ðət tɪl i wɑz sɪk ʌv ɪt.

"Too valuable," Mat finished for her drily. He had heard that till he was sick of it.

ʃi dɪsɹɪɡɑɹɾɪd ɪz sɑɹkæzəm, əɹ meɪbi dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs. ɪn ɪz ɪkspɪɹiəns, ɪf ə wʊmən dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ sʌmθɪŋ, ʃi kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt tɪl jə jɝsɛlf stɑɹɾəd tə daʊt jə hæd spoʊkən. "jɔɹ faɪnəli bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʌndɝstænd," ʃi dʒɹɔld, nɑɾɪŋ. "ðoʊz deɪmeɪn jəɹ soʊ wɝiɾ əbaʊt pɹɑbli doʊn ivən əv wɛls lɛf baɪ ðɪs taɪm." hɝ ɡeɪz wɛn tə ðə ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, ən sloʊli tʊk ɑn ə lʊk ə lɔs, meɪd dipɝ baɪ ðə hɑɹdnəs ə hɝ feɪs. hɝ θʌmz ɹæn əkɹɔs əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. "ju wʊdn bɪliv wʌt maɪ deɪmeɪn kɑs mi," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kwaɪət vɔɪs, "hɝ ən haɪɹɪŋ ðə sʌldəm fəɹ hɝ. wɝθ ɛvɹi θɹoʊn aɪ peɪd, ʌv kɔɹs. hɝ neɪmz sɛɹisə. wɛl-tʃɹeɪnd, ɹɪspɑnsɪv. ʃɪl ɡɔɹdʒ hɝsɛlf ɑn hʌnid nʌts, ɪf jə lɛt hɝ, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ ɡɛts sisɪk əɹ ðə sʌlks, ðə weɪ səm du. ə pɪɾi aɪ hæd tə liv əɹ ɪn kæntʃɹɪn. aɪ səpoʊz əl nɛvɝ si hɝ əɡɛn." ʃi saɪd ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli.

She disregarded his sarcasm, or maybe did not notice. In his experience, if a woman did not want to hear something, she could ignore it till you yourself started to doubt you had spoken. "You're finally beginning to understand," she drawled, nodding. "Those damane you're so worried about probably don't even have welts left by this time." Her gaze went to the ships in the harbor, and slowly took on a look of loss, made deeper by the hardness of her face. Her thumbs ran across her fingertips. "You wouldn't believe what my damane cost me," she said in a quiet voice, "her and hiring the sul'dam for her. Worth every throne I paid, of course. Her name's Serrisa. Well-trained, responsive. She'll gorge herself on honeyed nuts, if you let her, but she never gets seasick or the sulks, the way some do. A pity I had to leave her in Cantorin. I suppose I'll never see her again." She sighed regretfully.

"aɪm ʃʊɹ ʃi mɪsəz jə əz mʌtʃ əz jə mɪs hɝ," noʊl sɛd, flæʃɪŋ ə ɡæp-tuθ smaɪl, ən fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld, hi saʊndəd sənsɪɹ. meɪbi hi wɑz. hi kəntɛndɪd ðəɾ i hæd sin wɝs ðən deɪmeɪn ən dækoʊvæl, fəɹ wʌt ðət wɑz wɝθ.

"I'm sure she misses you as much as you miss her," Noal said, flashing a gap-toothed smile, and for all the world, he sounded sincere. Maybe he was. He contended that he had seen worse than damane and da'covale, for what that was worth.

ɛdʒiənɪnz bæk stɪfənd, ən ʃi fɹaʊn əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪz sɪmpəθi. əɹ ɛls ʃi hæd dʒʌst ɹilaɪz haʊ ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ. sɝɾənli, ʃi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝ vɛɹi dɪlɪbɝətli. "aɪ ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz ðət noʊ wʌn wɑz tə liv ðə wæɡənz," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. laɪkli, kɹumɪn ɑn əɹ ʃɪps hæd dʒʌmpt ət ðət toʊn. ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ hɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ əz ðoʊ ʃi ɪkspɛktəd mæt ən noʊl tə dʒʌmp wɛɹ ʃi ɪndəkeɪɾəd, tu.

Egeanin's back stiffened, and she frowned as if she did not believe his sympathy. Or else she had just realized how she was staring at the ships in the harbor. Certainly, she turned away from the water very deliberately. "I gave orders that no one was to leave the wagons," she said firmly. Likely, crewmen on her ships had jumped at that tone. She jerked her head away from the river as though she expected Mat and Noal to jump where she indicated, too.

"dɪd ju, naʊ?" mæt ɡɹɪnd, ʃoʊɪŋ əɹ tiθ. hi kəd mænədʒ ən ɪnsələnt ɡɹɪn ðət sɛn moʊs pʌft-ʌp fulz ɪndə æpəplɛksi. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ə ful, moʊs taɪmz, bʌt pʌft-ʌp ʃi wɑz.

"Did you, now?" Mat grinned, showing her teeth. He could manage an insolent grin that sent most puffed-up fools into apoplexy. Egeanin was far from a fool, most times, but puffed-up she was.

ʃɪp kæptən ən noʊbəlwʊmən. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ wɑz wɝs. bɑ fəɹ boʊθ! "wɛl, aɪ wɑz əbaʊt ɹɛɾi tə hɛd ðət weɪ. ənlɛs jəɹ nɑt dʌn fɪʃɪŋ, noʊl. wi kən weɪt hɪɹ ə waɪl, ɪf jəɹ nɑt." bʌt ði oʊl mæn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɛmptiɪŋ ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ mɪnoʊz aʊɾ ə hɪz bæskəɾ ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ. hɪz hænz hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən bædli, meɪbi mɔɹ ðən wʌns baɪ ðɛɹ lʌmpi əpɪɹəns, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ dɛft ɪn waɪndɪŋ ɪz laɪn ɝaʊn ðə bæmbu poʊl. ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt taɪm i hæd bɪn fɪʃɪŋ, hi hæd kɑt nɪɹli ə dʌzən fɪʃ, ðə lɑɹdʒəs lɛs ðən ə fʊt lɔŋ, stʃɹʌŋ θɹu ðə ɡɪlz ɑn ə lupt ɹid, ən i muv ðoʊz tə ðə bæskət bɪfɔɹ pɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp. hi kleɪm ðəɾ ɪf i kəd faɪn ðə ɹaɪt pɛpɝz, hi wɑz gɑnə meɪk ə fɪʃ stu  fɹəm ʃɑɹə, ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz! əz wɛl seɪ fɹəm ðə mun!  ə stu ðət wəd meɪk mæt fɝɡɛɾ ɔl əbaʊɾ ɪz hɪp. ðə weɪ noʊl wɛn ɑn əbaʊt ðə pɛpɝz, mæt səspɛktəɾ ɛni fɝɡɛɾɪŋ wəd bi kəz i wɑz foʊkəst ɑn faɪndɪŋ ɪnʌf eɪl tə kul ɪz tʌŋ.

Ship captain and noblewoman. He did not know which was worse. Bah for both! "Well, I was about ready to head that way. Unless you're not done fishing, Noal. We can wait here a while, if you're not." But the old man was already emptying the remaining silver-gray minnows out of his basket into the water. His hands had been broken badly, maybe more than once by their lumpy appearance, yet they were deft in winding his line around the bamboo pole. In the short time he had been fishing, he had caught nearly a dozen fish, the largest less than a foot long, strung through the gills on a looped reed, and he moved those to the basket before picking it up. He claimed that if he could find the right peppers, he was going to make a fish stew  from Shara, of all places! As well say from the moon!  a stew that would make Mat forget all about his hip. The way Noal went on about the peppers, Mat suspected any forgetting would be because he was focused on finding enough ale to cool his tongue.

ɛdʒiənɪn, weɪɾɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli, wɑz peɪɪŋ noʊ ətɛnʃən tə mæts ɡɹɪn, iðɝ, soʊ hi slɪpt ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɝ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ bæk, ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛt stɑɹɾəd. ʃi nɑkt ɪz hæn əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ðə wʊmən meɪd səm meɪɾən æns i hæd noʊn lʊk laɪk tævɝn ɡɝlz.

Egeanin, waiting impatiently, was paying no attention to Mat's grin, either, so he slipped an arm around her. If they were heading back, they might as well get started. She knocked his hand away from her shoulder. The woman made some maiden aunts he had known look like tavern girls.

"wɝ səpoʊz tə bi lʌvɝz, jə ən aɪ," hi ɹimaɪndəd hɝ.

"We're supposed to be lovers, you and I," he reminded her.

"ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi hɪɹ tə si," ʃi ɡɹaʊld.

"There's nobody here to see," she growled.

"haʊ mɛni taɪmz də aɪ hæv tə tɛl ju, laɪlwɪn?" ðət wɑz ðə neɪm ʃi wɑz juzɪŋ. ʃi kleɪmd ɪt wɑz tæɹɑbənɝ. əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt, ɪt dɪd nɑt saʊn sintʃæn. "ɪf wi doʊn ivən hoʊl hænz ənlɛs wi si sʌmbɑɾi wɑtʃɪŋ, wɝ gɑnə lʊk ə pɹɪɾi stʃɹeɪnʒ pɛɹ ə lʌvɝz tə ɛnibəɾi wi doʊn si."

"How many times do I have to tell you, Leilwin?" That was the name she was using. She claimed it was Taraboner. At any rate, it did not sound Seanchan. "If we don't even hold hands unless we see somebody watching, we're going to look a pretty strange pair of lovers to anybody we don't see."

ʃi snɔɹɾɪd ɪn dɝɪʒən, jɛt ʃi lɛɾ ɪm pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm bæk ɝaʊn hɝ, ən slɪp hɝz ɝaʊn hɪm. bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə wɔɹnɪŋ stɛɹ ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

She snorted in derision, yet she let him put his arm back around her, and slipped hers around him. But she gave him a warning stare at the same time.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ʃi wɑz kɹeɪzi əz ə spɹɪŋ hɛɹ ɪf ʃi θɔɾ i ɛndʒɔɪd ðɪs. moʊst wɪmən hæɾ ə lɪɾəl pæɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ mʌsəlz, ət lis ðə wɪmən i laɪkt, bʌt hʌɡɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz laɪk hʌɡɪŋ ə fɛns poʊst. ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹd, ən dɛfənətli əz stɪf. hi kəd nɑt pʌzəl aʊt wʌt doʊmən sɔ ɪn hɝ. meɪbi ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ði ɪliɑnɝ ɛni tʃɔɪs. ʃi hæd bɑt ðə mæn, æftɝ ɔl, seɪm əz baɪɪŋ ə hɔɹs. bɝn mi, əl nɛvɝ ʌndɝstæn ðiz sintʃæn, hi θɔt. nɑt ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə. ði oʊnli θɪŋ wɑz, hi hæd tə.

Mat shook his head. She was crazy as a spring hare if she thought he enjoyed this. Most women had a little padding over their muscles, at least the women he liked, but hugging Egeanin was like hugging a fence post. Almost as hard, and definitely as stiff. He could not puzzle out what Domon saw in her. Maybe she had not given the Illianer any choice. She had bought the man, after all, same as buying a horse. Burn me, I'll never understand these Seanchan, he thought. Not that he wanted to. The only thing was, he had to.

əz ðeɪ wɝ tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, hi tʊk wʌn læst ɡlæns bæk ət ðə hɑɹbɝ, ən ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt i hæd nɑt. tu smɔl seɪlɪŋ kɹæf bɹoʊk θɹu ə waɪd wɔl ə mɪs ðət wɑz dʒɹɪftɪŋ sloʊli daʊn ðə hɑɹbɝ.

As they were turning away, he took one last glance back at the harbor, and almost wished he had not. Two small sailing craft broke through a wide wall of mist that was drifting slowly down the harbor.

dʒɹɪftɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd. taɪm tə bi ɡɔn ən pæs taɪm.

Drifting against the wind. Time to be gone and past time.

ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən tu maɪlz fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ðə ɡɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, əkɹɔs ɹoʊlɪŋ kʌntʃɹisaɪd kʌvɝɾ ɪn wɪntɝ-bɹaʊn ɡɹæsəz ən widz ən dɑɾəd wɪð klʌmps ə vaɪn-tæŋɡəl bʊʃəz tu θɪk tə pʊʃ θɹu ivən wɪð moʊst ə ðə livz ɡɔn. ðə ɹaɪzəz hɑɹdli dɪzɝv ðə neɪm ə hɪl, nɑt fəɹ ɛniwʌn u hæd klaɪmd ɪn ðə sæn hɪlz ən ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst əz ə bɔɪ  ðəɹ wɝ ɡæps ɪn ɪz oʊn mɛmɹiz, bʌt mæt kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ səm ə ðæt  jɛt bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, hi wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn sʌmbɑɾi. hi hæd sæt moʊʃənləs ɑn ðət blʌɾi ɹɑk fəɹ tu lɔŋ. ðə θɹəb ɪn ɪz hɪp hæd feɪɾəd tə ə dʌl eɪk, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl meɪɾ ɪm lɪmp, ən wɪθaʊt səm sɔɹɾ ə səpɔɹt, hi wʊɾə bɪn stæɡɝɪŋ ɑn ðə sloʊps. nɑt ðəɾ i lin ɑn ɛdʒiənɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt hoʊldɪŋ ɑn hɛlp stɛɾi hɪm.

It was better than two miles from the river to the Great North Road, across rolling countryside covered in winter-brown grasses and weeds and dotted with clumps of vine-tangled bushes too thick to push through even with most of the leaves gone. The rises hardly deserved the name of hill, not for anyone who had climbed in the Sand Hills and the Mountains of Mist as a boy  there were gaps in his own memories, but Mat could remember some of that  yet before long, he was glad he had an arm around somebody. He had sat motionless on that bloody rock for too long. The throb in his hip had faded to a dull ache, but it still made him limp, and without some sort of support, he would have been staggering on the slopes. Not that he leaned on Egeanin, of course, but holding on helped steady him.

ðə wʊmən fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əz ðoʊ ʃi θɔɾ i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ.

The woman frowned at him as though she thought he were trying to take advantage.

"ɪf jə dɪɾ əz jə wɝ toʊld," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ wʊdnt nid tə kæɹi ju." hi ʃoʊɾ ɪz tiθ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsɡaɪz ɪɾ əz ə smaɪl. ðə weɪ noʊl skæmpɝɾ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪɾ əm izəli, nɛvɝ mɪsɪŋ ə stɛp dɪspaɪt bælənsɪŋ ɪz bæskəɾ ə fɪʃ ɑn ɪz hɪp wɪð wʌn hæn ən kæɹiɪŋ ɪz fɪʃɪŋ poʊl ɪn ði ʌðɝ, wɑz ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ. fəɹ ɔl i lʊk hɑɹd-wɔɹn, ði oʊl mæn wɑz spɹaɪ ɪnʌf. tu spɹaɪ baɪ hæf, ət taɪmz.

"If you did as you were told," she growled, "I wouldn't need to carry you." He showed his teeth again, this time not trying to disguise it as a smile. The way Noal scampered along beside them easily, never missing a step despite balancing his basket of fish on his hip with one hand and carrying his fishing pole in the other, was embarrassing. For all he looked hard-worn, the old man was spry enough. Too spry by half, at times.

ðɛɹ ɹut slæntəd nɔɹθ ə ðə sɝkəɾ ə hɛvən, wɪð ɪts lɔŋ, oʊpən-ɛndəd tiɹz ə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn sits wɛɹ, ɪn wɔɹmɝ wɛðɝ, wɛlθi peɪtʃɹənz sæɾ ɑn kʊʃənz bɪniθ kʌlɝfəl kænvəs ɔnɪŋz tə wɑtʃ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɹeɪs. naʊ, ði ɔnɪŋz ən poʊlz wɝ stoʊɾ əweɪ, ðə hɔɹsəz ɔl ɪn ðɛɹ kʌntʃɹi steɪbəlz, ðoʊz ðə sintʃæn hæd nɑt teɪkən, ən ðə sits wɝ ɛmpti seɪv fəɹ ə hændfʊl ə smɔl bɔɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə tiɹz ɪn ə ɡeɪm ə kip-əweɪ. mæt wɑz fɑn ə hɔɹsəz, ən ɹeɪsɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz slɪd pæs ðə sɝkət təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ. wɛnɛvɝ i tɑpt ə ɹaɪz, ðə sɪɾiz mæsɪv waɪt ɹæmpɑɹts wɝ vɪzəbəl, dip ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ səpɔɹɾəd ə ɹoʊɾ ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ðə sɪɾi ɑn tɑp, ən lʊkɪŋ ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɪkskjus tə pɔz ə moʊmənt. ful wʊmən! ə skɹæp ʌv ə lɪmp dɪd nɑt min ʃi wɑz kæɹiɪŋ hɪm! hi mænədʒ tə kip ə ɡʊd tɛmpɝ, teɪk ðə ɹʌf wɪð ðə smuð ən noʊ kəmpleɪnɪŋ. waɪ kəd ʃi nɑt?

Their route slanted north of the Circuit of Heaven, with its long, open-ended tiers of polished stone seats where, in warmer weather, wealthy patrons sat on cushions beneath colorful canvas awnings to watch their horses race. Now, the awnings and poles were stowed away, the horses all in their country stables, those the Seanchan had not taken, and the seats were empty save for a handful of small boys darting up and down the tiers in a game of keep-away. Mat was fond of horses, and racing, but his eyes slid past the Circuit toward Ebou Dar. Whenever he topped a rise, the city's massive white ramparts were visible, deep enough that they supported a road encircling the city on top, and looking gave him an excuse to pause a moment. Fool woman! A scrap of a limp did not mean she was carrying him! He managed to keep a good temper, take the rough with the smooth and no complaining. Why could she not?

ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi waɪt ɹufs ən wɔlz, waɪt doʊmz ən spaɪɹz, ɹɪŋd ɪn θɪn bænz ə kʌlɝ, ɡlimd ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, ə pɪktʃɝ ə sɝɛnəɾi. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə ɡæps wɛɹ bɪldɪŋz hæd bɝn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ə lɔŋ laɪn ə fɑɹmɝz' haɪ-wild ɑks-kɑɹts wɑz tʃɹʌnlɪŋ θɹu ðə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪtweɪ ðəɾ oʊpən ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, mɛn ən wɪmən ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə sɪɾi mɑɹkəts wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd lɛf tə sɛl ðɪs leɪɾ ɪn wɪntɝ, ən ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst ə mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn ə bɪɡ, kænvəs-tɑpt wæɡənz bɪhaɪn sɪks ən eɪt-hɔɹs timz, kæɹiɪŋ ɡʊdz fɹəm ðə laɪt nu wɛɹ. sɛvən mɔɹ tʃɹeɪnz, ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm fɔɹ wæɡənz tə tɛn, stʊɾ ɪn laɪn ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd tə weɪt fəɹ ðə ɡeɪtɛɡɑɹdz tə fɪnɪʃ ðɛɹ ɪnspɛkʃənz. tʃɹeɪd nɛvɝ stɑpt ɪntaɪɝli waɪl ðə sʌn ʃoʊn, noʊ mæɾɝ u ɹuld ə sɪɾi, ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz æktʃəwəl faɪɾɪŋ. səmtaɪmz ɪt dɪd nɑt stɑp kəmplitli ðɛn. ðə stʃɹim ə pipəl floʊɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ wɑz moʊsli sintʃæn, soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɔɹɾɝd ɹæŋks wɪð ðɛɹ sɛɡmɛntɪɾ ɑɹmɝ peɪntəɾ ɪn stʃɹaɪps ən hɛlməts ðət lʊk laɪk ðə hɛdz ə hjudʒ ɪnsɛks, səm mɑɹtʃɪŋ ən səm maʊntəd, noʊbəlz u wɝ ɔlweɪz maʊntəd, wɛɹɪŋ ɔɹneɪt kloʊks, pliɾɪd ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz ən leɪs veɪlz, əɹ vəlumənəs tʃɹaʊzɝz ən lɔŋ koʊts. sintʃæn sɛtlɝz wɝ stɪl dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, tu, wæɡən əpɑn wæɡən fɪld wɪð fɑɹmɝz ən kɹæfsmən ən ðə tulz ə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪdz. ðə sɛtlɝz hæd bɪɡʌn livɪŋ əz sun əz ðeɪ keɪm ɔf ðə ʃɪps, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi wiks bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɔn. ɪt wɑz ə pisfəl sin, wɝkədeɪ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪf jə ɪɡnɔɹd wʌt leɪ bɪhaɪn ɪt, jɛɾ ɛvɹi taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə pleɪs wɛɹ i kəd si ðə ɡeɪts, hɪz maɪn flæʃt bæk tə sɪks naɪts əɡoʊ, ən i wɑz ðəɹ əɡɛn, ət ðoʊz seɪm ɡeɪts.

Inside the city white roofs and walls, white domes and spires, ringed in thin bands of color, gleamed in the gray morning light, a picture of serenity. He could not make out the gaps where buildings had burned to the ground. A long line of farmers' high-wheeled ox-carts was trundling through the wide arched gateway that opened on the Great North Road, men and women on their way to the city markets with whatever they had left to sell this late in winter, and in their midst a merchant's train of big, canvas-topped wagons behind six and eight-horse teams, carrying goods from the Light knew where. Seven more trains, ranging from four wagons to ten, stood in line at the side of the road to wait for the gateguards to finish their inspections. Trade never stopped entirely while the sun shone, no matter who ruled a city, unless there was actual fighting. Sometimes it did not stop completely then. The stream of people flowing the other way was mostly Seanchan, soldiers in ordered ranks with their segmented armor painted in stripes and helmets that looked like the heads of huge insects, some marching and some mounted, nobles who were always mounted, wearing ornate cloaks, pleated riding dresses and lace veils, or voluminous trousers and long coats. Seanchan settlers were still departing the city, too, wagon upon wagon filled with farmers and craftsmen and the tools of their trades. The settlers had begun leaving as soon as they came off the ships, but it would be weeks before they were all gone. It was a peaceful scene, workaday and ordinary if you ignored what lay behind it, yet every time they reached a place where he could see the gates, his mind flashed back to six nights ago, and he was there again, at those same gates.

ðə stɔɹm hæd ɡɹoʊn wɝs əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə sɪɾi fɹəm ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. ɹeɪn fɛl baɪ bʌkəts, paʊndɪŋ ðə dɑɹkən sɪɾi ən slɪkɪŋ ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz, ən wɪn haʊld ɔf ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn laɪk stoʊnz fɹəm slɪŋz ən dʒɝkɪŋ ət kloʊks soʊ ðət kipɪŋ əɾ ɔl dʒɹaɪ wɑz ə lɔs kɑz. klaʊdz hɪd ðə mun, ən ðə dɛljudʒ sim tə soʊk ʌp ðə laɪɾ ə ðə poʊl-læntɝnz kæɹid baɪ blɹɪk ən fɛn, ɑn fʊɾ əhɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛst. ðən ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə lɔŋ pæsədʒweɪ θɹu ðə sɪɾi wɔl, ən ɡeɪn ə bɪɾ ə ʃɛltɝ, ət lis fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn. ðə wɪn meɪd ðə haɪ-silɪŋɡd tʌnəl kin laɪk ə flut. ðə ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə pæsədʒ, fɔɹ ə ðɛm ɔlsoʊ bɛɹɪŋ poʊl-læntɝnz. ə dʌzən mɔɹ, hæf ə ðɛm sintʃæn, kæɹid hælbɝdz ðət kəd stʃɹaɪk əɾ ə mæn ɪn ðə sæɾəl əɹ pʊl ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. tu sintʃæn wɪð ðɛɹ hɛlməts ɔf wɝ piɹɪŋ fɹəm ðə laɪɾəd dɔɹweɪ ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs bɪlt ɪndə ðə waɪt-plæstɝd wɔl, ən ʃɪftɪŋ ʃædoʊz bɪhaɪn əm toʊld ʌv ʌðɝz ɪnsaɪd. tu mɛni tə faɪt pæs kwaɪətli, meɪbi tu mɛni tə faɪt pæst əɾ ɔl. nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf laɪk ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz faɪɝwɝk bɝstɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd.

The storm had grown worse as they crossed the city from the Tarasin Palace. Rain fell by buckets, pounding the darkened city and slicking the paving stones under the horses' hooves, and wind howled off the Sea of Storms, driving the rain like stones from slings and jerking at cloaks so that keeping at all dry was a lost cause. Clouds hid the moon, and the deluge seemed to soak up the light of the pole-lanterns carried by Blaeric and Fen, on foot ahead of the rest. Then they entered the long passageway through the city wall, and gained a bit of shelter, at least from the rain. The wind made the high-ceilinged tunnel keen like a flute. The gate guards were waiting just inside the far end of the passage, four of them also bearing pole-lanterns. A dozen more, half of them Seanchan, carried halberds that could strike at a man in the saddle or pull him out of it. Two Seanchan with their helmets off were peering from the lighted doorway of the guardhouse built into the white-plastered wall, and shifting shadows behind them told of others inside. Too many to fight past quietly, maybe too many to fight past at all. Not without everything going off like an Illuminator's firework bursting in his hand.

ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ nɑt ðə deɪnʒɝ, ɛniweɪ, nɑt ðə meɪn deɪnʒɝ. ə tɔl, plʌmp-feɪst wʊmən ɪn dɑɹk blu, hɝ dɪvaɪɾəd æŋkəl-lɛŋθ skɝts bɛɹɪŋ ɹɛd pænəlz wɝkt wɪð sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, stɛpt pæs ðə mɛn ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs dɔɹ. ə lɔŋ sɪlvɝi mɛɾəl liʃ wɑz kɔɪld ɪn ðə sʌldəmz lɛf hænd, ðə fɹi ɛn kənɛktɪŋ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən ɪn ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs u fɑloʊɾ əɹ aʊt wɪð ən iɡɝ ɡɹɪn. mæt hæd noʊn ðeɪ wəd bi ðɛɹ. ðə sintʃæn hæd sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn əɾ ɔl ðə ɡeɪts, naʊ. ðəɹ kəɾ ivən bi ənʌðɝ pɛɹ ɪnsaɪd, əɹ tu. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt min tə lɛt wʌn wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl ɪskeɪp ðɛɹ nɛts. ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd mədæljən bɪniθ ɪz ʃɝt leɪ koʊld əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst; nɑt ðə koʊl ðət sɪɡnəl sʌmwʌn ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs nɪɹbaɪ, dʒʌs ði əkjumjəleɪɾəd tʃɪl ə ðə naɪɾ ən ɪz flɛʃ tu aɪsi tə wɔɹm ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝ. laɪt, hi wɑz dʒʌɡəlɪŋ faɪɹwɝks tənaɪt, wɪð ðə fjuzəz lɪt!

The guards were not the danger, anyway, not the main danger. A tall, plump-faced woman in dark blue, her divided ankle-length skirts bearing red panels worked with silver lightning bolts, stepped past the men in the guardhouse door. A long silvery metal leash was coiled in the sul'dam's left hand, the free end connecting her to the graying woman in a dark gray dress who followed her out with an eager grin. Mat had known they would be there. The Seanchan had sul'dam and damane at all the gates, now. There could even be another pair inside, or two. They did not mean to let one woman who could channel escape their nets. The silver foxhead medallion beneath his shirt lay cold against his chest; not the cold that signaled someone embracing the Source nearby, just the accumulated chill of the night and his flesh too icy to warm it, but he could not stop waiting for the other. Light, he was juggling fireworks tonight, with the fuses lit!

ðə ɡɑɹdz maɪɾ əv bɪn pʌzəl baɪ ə noʊbəlwʊmən livɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪɾ ən ðət wɛðɝ, wɪð oʊvɝ ə dʌzən sɝvəns ən stʃɹɪŋz ə pækhɔɹsɪz ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ ə dʒɝni ʌv səm dɪstəns, bʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ə ðə blʌd, hɝ kloʊk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ən iɡəl wɪð spɹɛd blæk-ænd-waɪt wɪŋz, ən lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn əɹ ɹɛd ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz tə əkɑmədeɪɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz. ɔɹɾənɛɹi soʊlʒɝz dɪd nɑt kwɛstʃən wʌt ðə blʌd tʃoʊz tə du, ivən ðə loʊ blʌd. wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt min ðəɹ wɝ noʊ fɔɹmæləɾiz. ɛniwʌn wɑz fɹi tə liv ðə sɪɾi wən ðeɪ wɪʃt, bʌt ðə sintʃæn ɹəkɔɹɾəd ðə muvmən ə deɪmeɪn, ən θɹi ɹoʊɾ ɪn ði ɑntʊɹɑʒ, hɛdz daʊn ən feɪsəz kʌvɝd baɪ ðə hʊdz ə ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪ kloʊks, itʃ lɪŋk tə ə maʊntəd sʌldəm baɪ ðə sɪlvɝi lɛŋθ ʌv ən æɾəm.

The guards might have been puzzled by a noblewoman leaving Ebou Dar in the middle of the night and that weather, with over a dozen servants and strings of packhorses indicating a journey of some distance, but Egeanin was of the Blood, her cloak embroidered in an eagle with spread black-and-white wings, and long fingers on her red riding gloves to accommodate her fingernails. Ordinary soldiers did not question what the Blood chose to do, even the low Blood. Which did not mean there were no formalities. Anyone was free to leave the city when they wished, but the Seanchan recorded the movement of damane, and three rode in the entourage, heads down and faces covered by the hoods of their gray cloaks, each linked to a mounted sul'dam by the silvery length of an a'dam.

ðə plʌmp-feɪst sʌldəm wɔk baɪ ðɛm wɪð bɛɹli ə ɡlæns, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn ðə tʌnəl. hɝ deɪmeɪn pɪɹɾ ɪntɛnli əɾ ɛvɹi wʊmən ðeɪ pæst, ðoʊ, sɛnsɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi kəd tʃænəl, ən mæt hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ wən ʃi pɔz bɪsaɪd ðə læs maʊntəd deɪmeɪn wɪð ə slaɪt fɹaʊn. ivən wɪð ɪz lʌk, hi wəd nɑt bɛɾ əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz eɪdʒləs feɪs ɪf ðeɪ lʊkt ɪnsaɪd ðət hʊd. ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ hɛld əz deɪmeɪn, bʌt wʌt wɝ ði ɑdz ðəɾ ɔl θɹi ʌv ɛdʒiənɪnz wəd bi? laɪt, wʌt wɝ ði ɑdz wʌn ə ðə loʊ blʌd wəɾ oʊn θɹi?

The plump-faced sul'dam walked by them with barely a glance, strolling down the tunnel. Her damane peered intently at every woman they passed, though, sensing whether she could channel, and Mat held his breath when she paused beside the last mounted damane with a slight frown. Even with his luck, he would not bet against the Seanchan recognizing an Aes Sedai's ageless face if they looked inside that hood. There were Aes Sedai held as damane, but what were the odds that all three of Egeanin's would be? Light, what were the odds one of the low Blood would own three?
