ðə plʌmp-feɪst wʊmən meɪɾ ə klɪkɪŋ saʊnd, əz jə maɪt tə ə pɛt dɔɡ, ən twɪtʃt ði æɾəm, ən ðə deɪmeɪn fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɑn. ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp ðə liʃ, nɑt deɪmeɪn. mæt stɪl θɔɾ i maɪt tʃoʊk. ðə saʊn ə daɪs ɹoʊlɪŋ hæd stɑɹɾəd ʌp əɡɛn ɪn ɪz hɛd, laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹaɪvəl ði əkeɪʒənəl ɹʌmbəl ə dɪstən θʌndɝ. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz gɑnə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ; hi nu ɪt.

The plump-faced woman made a clicking sound, as you might to a pet dog, and twitched the a'dam, and the damane followed her on. They were looking for marath'damane trying to escape the leash, not damane. Mat still thought he might choke. The sound of dice rolling had started up again in his head, loud enough to rival the occasional rumble of distant thunder. Something was going to go wrong; he knew it.

ði ɔfəsɝ ə ðə ɡɑɹdz, ə bɝli sintʃæn wɪð tɪltəɾ aɪz laɪk ə sɑldəiən bʌɾ ə peɪl hʌni-bɹaʊn skɪn, baʊd kɔɝɾiəsli ən ɪnvaɪɾəd ɛdʒiənɪn ɪndə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs, tə hæv ə kʌp ə spaɪst waɪn waɪl ə klɝk ɹoʊt daʊn ði ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðə deɪmeɪn. ɛvɹi ɡɑɹdhaʊs mæt hæɾ ɛvɝ sin wɑz ə stɑɹk pleɪs, jɛt ðə læmplaɪt ɡloʊɪŋ ɪn ði æɹoʊslɪts meɪd ðɪs wʌn sim ɔlmoʊst ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ. ə pɪtʃɝplæn pɹɑbli lʊkt ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ tə ə flaɪ, tu. hi hæd bɪn ɡlæɾ ə ðə ɹeɪn dʒɹɪpɪŋ fɹəm ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk ən ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ɪz feɪs. ɪt dɪsɡaɪz ðə swɛɾ ə nɝvz. hi hɛld wʌn ə hɪz θɹoʊɪŋ naɪvz, ɹɛstɪŋ flæɾ ətɑp ðə lɔŋ bʌndəl dʒɹeɪpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz sæɾəl. laɪɪŋ flæt laɪk ðæt, nʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ʃəd noʊɾəs. hi kəd fil ðə wʊmən ɪnsaɪd ðə klɔθ bɹiðɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz hænz, ən ɪz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ nɑɾɪd fɹəm weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə kɹaɪ aʊt fəɹ hɛlp. sɪlutʃə kɛpt əɹ maʊn kloʊs tə hɪm, piɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə ʃɛltɝ ə hɝ hʊd wɪð əɹ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd tʌkt aʊɾ ə saɪt, nɛvɝ ivən ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ wən ðə sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn wɔk baɪ. ə ʃaʊt fɹəm sɪlutʃə wʊɾə pʊt ðə wizəl ɪn ðə tʃɪkən ɹʌn əz mʌtʃ əz wʌn fɹəm tuɑn. hi θɔt ðə θɹɛɾ ə ðə naɪf hæd hɛl boʊθ wɪmən saɪlənt  ðeɪ hæd tə bɪliv i wɑz dɛspɹɪɾ ɪnʌf əɹ kɹeɪzi ɪnʌf tə juz ɪt  bʌɾ i stɪl kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt naɪɾ i kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ ʌv, soʊ mʌtʃ ɔf-bæləns ən əskju.

The officer of the guards, a burly Seanchan with tilted eyes like a Saldaean but a pale honey-brown skin, bowed courteously and invited Egeanin into the guardhouse, to have a cup of spiced wine while a clerk wrote down the information about the damane. Every guardhouse Mat had ever seen was a stark place, yet the lamplight glowing in the arrowslits made this one seem almost inviting. A pitcherplant probably looked inviting to a fly, too. He had been glad of the rain dripping from the hood of his cloak and running down his face. It disguised the sweat of nerves. He held one of his throwing knives, resting flat atop the long bundle draped in front of his saddle. Lying flat like that, none of the soldiers should notice. He could feel the woman inside the cloth breathing under his hands, and his shoulders were knotted from waiting for her to cry out for help. Selucia kept her mount close to him, peering at him from the shelter of her hood with her golden braid tucked out of sight, never even glancing away when the sul'dam and damane walked by. A shout from Selucia would have put the weasel in the chicken run as much as one from Tuon. He thought the threat of the knife had held both women silent  they had to believe he was desperate enough or crazy enough to use it  but he still could not be sure. There was so much about night he could not be sure of, so much off-balance and askew.

hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ, wʌndɝɪŋ wən sʌmwʌn wəd noʊɾəs ðət ðə bʌndəl i kæɹid wɑz ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ən kwɛstʃən waɪ hi wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ɪt ɡɛt soʊkt wɪð ɹeɪn, wʌndɝɪŋ ən kɝsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ɡɹæbɪŋ ə wɔlhænʒɪŋ kəz ɪt hæd bɪn kloʊz tə hænd. ɪn mɛmɹi, ɛvɹiθɪŋ sloʊd. ɛdʒiənɪn stɛp daʊn, tɔsɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə doʊmən, hu tʊk əm wɪð ə baʊ fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl.

He remembered holding his breath, wondering when someone would notice that the bundle he carried was richly embroidered and question why he was letting it get soaked with rain, wondering and cursing himself for grabbing a wallhanging because it had been close to hand. In memory, everything slowed. Egeanin stepped down, tossing her reins to Domon, who took them with a bow from his saddle.

doʊmənz hʊd wɑz pʊʃt bæk dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ðəɾ ɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən ɪz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɛɹ ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ə bɹeɪd ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɹeɪndʒɹɑps dʒɹɪp fɹəm ðə stɑki ɪliɑnɝz ʃɔɹt bɪɹd, jɛɾ i mænədʒ ðə pɹɑpɝ stɪf-nɛkt ɛɹəɡəns ʌv ə sɔɪhɪn, hɝɛɾətɛɹi ʌpɝ sɝvən tə wʌn ə ðə blʌɾ ən ðʌs ɔlmoʊst ikwəl tə ðə blʌd. dɛfənətli haɪɝ ðən ɛni kɑmən soʊlʒɝ. ɛdʒiənɪn ɡlæns bæk təwɔɹd mæt ən ɪz bɝɾən, hɝ feɪs ə fɹoʊzən mæsk ðət kəd pæs fəɹ hoʊtʊɹ ɪf jə dɪd nɑt noʊ ʃi wɑz hɔɹəfaɪd baɪ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. ðə tɔl sʌldəm ən əɹ deɪmeɪn tɝn bɹɪskli bæk ʌp ðə tʌnəl, fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðɛɹ ɪnspɛkʃən. veɪnɪn, dʒʌs bɪhaɪn mæt liɾɪŋ wʌn ə ðə stʃɹɪŋz ə pækhɔɹsɪz ən əz ɔlweɪz sɪɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs laɪk ə sæk ə sut, lin fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən spæt. mæt dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ ðət hʌŋ ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd. veɪnɪn spæt, ən tʃɹʌmpəts saʊndəd, θɪn ən ʃɑɹp ɪn ðə dɪstəns fɑɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. fɹəm saʊθ ə ðə sɪɾi, wɛɹ mɛn hæd bɪn plænɪŋ tə faɪɝ sintʃæn səplaɪz stɔɹɾ əlɔŋ ðə beɪ ɹoʊd.

Domon's hood was pushed back just enough to show that his head was shaved on one side and his remaining hair gathered in a braid that hung to his shoulder. Raindrops dripped from the stocky Illianer's short beard, yet he managed the proper stiff-necked arrogance of a so'jhin, hereditary upper servant to one of the Blood and thus almost equal to the Blood. Definitely higher than any common soldier. Egeanin glanced back toward Mat and his burden, her face a frozen mask that could pass for hauteur if you did not know she was horrified by what they were doing. The tall sul'dam and her damane turned briskly back up the tunnel, finished with their inspection. Vanin, just behind Mat leading one of the strings of packhorses and as always sitting his horse like a sack of suet, leaned from his saddle and spat. Mat did not know why that hung in his memory, but it did. Vanin spat, and trumpets sounded, thin and sharp in the distance far behind them. From south of the city, where men had been planning to fire Seanchan supplies stored along the Bay Road.

ði ɔfəsɝ ə ðə ɡɑɹd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ət ðə saʊn ə ðə tʃɹʌmpəts, bʌt sʌɾənli ə bɛl pild laʊdli ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf, ðən ənʌðɝ, ən ðən ɪt sim hʌnʒɹədz wɝ klæŋɪŋ əlɑɹm ɪn ðə naɪɾ əz ðə blæk skaɪ splɪt wɪð mɔɹ laɪtnɪŋ ðən ɛni stɔɹm hæɾ ɛvɝ bɝθɛd, sɪlvɝ-blu stʃɹiks stæbɪŋ daʊn ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz. ðeɪ beɪðd ðə tʌnəl ɪn flɪkɝɪŋ laɪt. ðət wɑz wən ðə ʃaʊɾɪŋ stɑɹɾəd, əmɪd ði ɪksploʊʒənz bæk ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən ðə skɹimɪŋ.

The officer of the guard hesitated at the sound of the trumpets, but suddenly a bell pealed loudly in the city itself, then another, and then it seemed hundreds were clanging alarm in the night as the black sky split with more lightning than any storm had ever birthed, silver-blue streaks stabbing down inside the walls. They bathed the tunnel in flickering light. That was when the shouting started, amid the explosions back in the city, and the screaming.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, mæt hæd kɝs ðə wɪndfɪndɝz fəɹ muvɪŋ sunɝ ðən i hæd bɪn pɹɑməst.

For a moment, Mat had cursed the Windfinders for moving sooner than he had been promised.

bʌt ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd hæd stɑpt, hi ɹilaɪzd. waɪ? ɪt meɪɾ ɪm wɑnə kɝs ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ivən ðæt. ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən ði ɔfəsɝ wɑz hɝidli ɝdʒɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪn bæk ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl ən ɑn əɹ weɪ, hɝidli ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz tə ðə mɛn bɔɪlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs, dɝɛktɪŋ wʌn ɪndə ðə sɪɾi əɾ ə ɹʌn tə si wʌt ði əlɑɹm wɑz waɪl i ɝeɪd ðə ɹɛst əɡɛnst ɛni θɹɛt fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ aʊt. ðə plʌmp-feɪst wʊmən ɹæn tə pleɪs hɝsɛlf ən əɹ deɪmeɪn wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz, əlɔŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ pɛɹ ʌv wɪmən lɪŋk baɪ ən æɾəm, hu keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡɑɹdhaʊs. ən mæt ən ði ʌðɝz ɡæləpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stɔɹm, kæɹiɪŋ wɪð əm θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu ʌv əm ɪskeɪp deɪmeɪn, ən ðə kɪdnæpt ɛɹ tə ðə sintʃæn kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, waɪl bɪhaɪn əm ə fɑɹ wɝs stɔɹm bɹoʊk oʊvɝ ɛbu dɑɹ. laɪtnɪŋ boʊls mɔɹ numɝəs ðən bleɪdz ʌv ɡɹæs....

But the dice in his head had stopped, he realized. Why? It made him want to curse all over again, but there was no time for even that. In the next instant the officer was hurriedly urging Egeanin back into her saddle and on her way, hurriedly shouting orders to the men boiling out of the guardhouse, directing one into the city at a run to see what the alarm was while he arrayed the rest against any threat from inside or out. The plump-faced woman ran to place herself and her damane with the soldiers, along with another pair of women linked by an a'dam, who came running from the guardhouse. And Mat and the others galloped out into the storm, carrying with them three Aes Sedai, two of them escaped damane, and the kidnaped heir to the Seanchan Crystal Throne, while behind them a far worse storm broke over Ebou Dar. Lightning bolts more numerous than blades of grass....

wɪð ə ʃɪvɝ, mæt pʊl hɪmsɛlf bæk tə ðə pɹɛzənt. ɛdʒiənɪn skaʊld ət hɪm, ən ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd pʊl. "lʌvɝz ɑɹm-ɪn-ɑɹm doʊn hɝi," hi mʌɾɝd. "ðeɪstʃɹoʊl." ʃi snɪɹd. doʊmən hæd tə bi blaɪndɪd baɪ lʌv. ðæt, əɹ i hæd teɪkən tu mɛni θʌmps ɑn ðə hɛd.

With a shiver, Mat pulled himself back to the present. Egeanin scowled at him, and gave him an exaggerated pull. "Lovers arm-in-arm don't hurry," he muttered. "They...stroll." She sneered. Domon had to be blinded by love. That, or he had taken too many thumps on the head.

ðə wɝst wɑz oʊvɝ ən dʌn, ɪn ɛni keɪs. mæt hoʊp ðət ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi hæd bɪn ðə wɝst. hi hæd nɑt fɛl ðə daɪs sɪns. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlweɪz ə bæd saɪn. hɪz bæktʃɹeɪl wɑz əz mʌɾəld əz i kəd mænədʒ, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd teɪk sʌmwʌn əz lʌki əz i tə sɛpɝeɪt ðə ɡoʊl fɹəm ðə dʒɹɔs.

The worst was over and done, in any case. Mat hoped that getting out of the city had been the worst. He had not felt the dice since. They were always a bad sign. His backtrail was as muddled as he could manage, and he was sure it would take someone as lucky as he to separate the gold from the dross.

ðə sikɝz hæd bɪn ɑn ɛdʒiənɪnz sɛn bɪfɔɹ ðət naɪt, ən ʃi wəd bi wɑntəɾ ɑn tʃɑɹdʒəz ə stilɪŋ deɪmeɪn naʊ, əz wɛl, bʌt ði əθɔɹəɾiz wəɾ ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kəɾ ən ɔlɹɛɾi liɡz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, nɑt sɪɾɪŋ dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns ə taɪmɪŋ kənɛktəɾ əɹ tə tuɑn. əɹ tə mæt, ən ðət wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. taɪlɪn sɝɾənli wʊɾə lɛvəld əɹ oʊn tʃɑɹdʒəz əɡɛns hɪm  noʊ wʊmən wɑz gɑnə fɝɡɪv ə mæn taɪɪŋ əɹ ʌp ən ʃʌvɪŋ əɹ ʌndɝ ə bɛd, ivən wən ʃi hæd sədʒɛstəɾ ɪt  jɛt wɪð ɛni lʌk, hi wɑz bɪniθ səspɪʃən fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðət hæd hæpən ðət naɪt. wɪð ɛni lʌk, noʊ wʌn ɪksɛp taɪlɪn hæɾ ə θɔt fəɹ ɪm əɾ ɔl. tʃɹʌsɪŋ ə kwin laɪk ə pɪɡ fəɹ mɑɹkət wəd bi ɪnʌf tə ɡɛɾ ə mæn dɛd juʒəwəli, bʌɾ ɪt hæd tə kaʊn fəɹ moʊldi ʌnjənz əlɔŋsaɪd ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ, ən wʌt kəd taɪlɪnz tɔɪ hæv tə də wɪð ðæt? ɪt stɪl ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɪm ðəɾ i hæd bɪn sin əz ə hæŋɝ-ɑn  wɝs, ə pɛt!  bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ædvæntɪdʒɪz.

The Seekers had been on Egeanin's scent before that night, and she would be wanted on charges of stealing damane now, as well, but the authorities would expect her to be riding as hard as she could and already leagues from Ebou Dar, not sitting just outside the city. Nothing except a coincidence of timing connected her to Tuon. Or to Mat, and that was important. Tylin certainly would have leveled her own charges against him  no woman was going to forgive a man tying her up and shoving her under a bed, even when she had suggested it  yet with any luck, he was beneath suspicion for anything else that had happened that night. With any luck, no one except Tylin had a thought for him at all. Trussing a queen like a pig for market would be enough to get a man dead usually, but it had to count for moldy onions alongside the Daughter of the Nine Moons disappearing, and what could Tylin's Toy have to do with that? It still irritated him that he had been seen as a hanger-on  worse, a pet!  but there were advantages.

hi θɔɾ i wɑz seɪf  fɹəm ðə sintʃæn, ɛniweɪ  jɛt wʌn pɔɪnt wɝiɾ ɪm laɪk ə θɔɹn bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɪz hil. wɛl, sɛvɹəl dɪd, moʊst ɡɹoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ə tuɑn hɝsɛlf, bʌt ðɪs wʌn hæɾ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli lɔŋ pɔɪnt. tuɑnz dɪsəpɪɹəns ʃʊɾə bɪn əz ʃɑkɪŋ əz ðə sʌn vænɪʃɪŋ ət nun, bʌt noʊ əlɑɹm hæd bɪn ɹeɪzd. nʌn! noʊ ənaʊnsməns ə ɹɪwɔɹdz əɹ ɔfɝz ə ɹænsəm, noʊ hɑt-aɪd soʊlʒɝz sɝtʃɪŋ ɛvɹi wæɡən ən kɑɹt wɪðɪn maɪlz, ɡæləpɪŋ θɹu ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd tə ɹuɾ aʊɾ ɛvɹi kʌbihoʊl ən nɪtʃ wɛɹ ə wʊmən maɪt bi hɪɾən. ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz toʊld ɪm sʌmθɪŋ ə hʌntɪŋ fəɹ kɪdnæpt ɹɔɪəlti, jɛɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə hæŋʒɪŋz ən ðə bɝnd ʃɪps ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪɾ ɛbu dɑɹ simd əntʃeɪnʒd fɹəm ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə kɪdnæpɪŋ. ɛdʒiənɪn əlɛdʒ ðət ðə sɝtʃ wəd bi ɪn ʌɾɝ sikɹəsi, ðət mɛni ʌv ðə sintʃæn ðɛmsɛlvz maɪt stɪl nɑt noʊ tuɑn wɑz mɪsɪŋ.

He thought he was safe  from the Seanchan, anyway  yet one point worried him like a thorn buried in his heel. Well, several did, most growing out of Tuon herself, but this one had a particularly long point. Tuon's disappearance should have been as shocking as the sun vanishing at noon, but no alarm had been raised. None! No announcements of rewards or offers of ransom, no hot-eyed soldiers searching every wagon and cart within miles, galloping through the countryside to root out every cubbyhole and niche where a woman might be hidden. Those old memories told him something of hunting for kidnapped royalty, yet except for the hangings and the burned ships in the harbor, from the outside Ebou Dar seemed unchanged from the day before the kidnaping. Egeanin alleged that the search would be in utter secrecy, that many of the Seanchan themselves might still not know Tuon was missing.

hɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən ɪnvɑlv ðə ʃɑk tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ ən ɪl oʊmənz fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn ən ðə lɔs ə seɪaɪtɑɹ, ən ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi bɪlivd ɛvɹi wɝd, bʌt mæt ɹəfjuz tə baɪ ə pɛniz wɝθ. ðə sintʃæn wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ foʊk, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəd bi ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ. ðə saɪləns ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ meɪɾ ɪz skɪn pɹɪkəl. hi fɛlt ə tʃɹæp ɪn ðət saɪləns. wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, hi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl ðət ðə sɪɾi wɑz hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə loʊ hɪlz.

Her explanation involved the shock to the Empire and ill omens for the Return and the loss of sei'taer, and she sounded as if she believed every word, but Mat refused to buy a penny's worth. The Seanchan were strange folk, but no one could be that strange. The silence of Ebou Dar made his skin prickle. He felt a trap in that silence. When they reached the Great North Road, he was grateful that the city was hidden behind the low hills.

ðə ɹoʊd wɑz ə bɹɔd haɪweɪ, ə meɪdʒɝ ævənu ʌv tʃɹeɪd, waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ faɪv əɹ sɪks wæɡənz əbɹɛst ʌnkɹaʊɾəd, wɪð ə sɝfəs ə dɝɾ ən kleɪ ðət hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz ə jus hæd pæk nɪɹli əz hɑɹɾ əz ði əkeɪʒənəl eɪntʃən peɪvɪŋ stoʊn ðət stʌk ən ɛdʒ əɹ kɔɹnɝ ɪntʃəz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. mæt ən ɛdʒiənɪn hɝiɾ əkɹɔs tə ðə vɝdʒ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd wɪð noʊl dɔɡɪŋ ðɛɹ hilz, bɪtwin ə mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn ɹʌmbəlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi, ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ ə skɑɹ-feɪst wʊmən ən tɛn hɑɹd-aɪd mɛn ɪn lɛðɝ vɛsts kʌvɝd wɪð mɛɾəl dɪsks, ən ə stʃɹɪŋ ə ðə sɛtlɝz' ɑdli ʃeɪpt wæɡənz, ɹaɪzɪŋ tə piks ət ði ɛnz, ðət wɝ hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ, səm pʊl baɪ hɔɹsəz əɹ mjulz, ʌðɝz baɪ ɑksən. klʌstɝd bɪtwin ðə wæɡənz, bɛɹfʊt bɔɪz juz swɪtʃəz tə hɝd fɔɹ-hɔɹnd ɡoʊts wɪð lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ ən bɪɡ, dulæpt waɪt kaʊz. wʌn mæn ət ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə wæɡənz, ɪn bæɡi blu bɹitʃɪz ən ə ɹaʊn ɹɛd kæp, wɑz liɾɪŋ ə mæsɪv hʌmp-bæk bʊl baɪ ə θɪk kɔɹd taɪd tə ə ɹɪŋ ɪn ɪts noʊz. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz kloʊðz, hi cʊɾə bɪn fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hi aɪd mæt ən ði ʌðɝz, wɔkɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən, əz ɪf i maɪt spik, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən plɑɾəd ɑn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ əm əɡɛn. kəntɛndɪŋ wɪð mæts lɪmp, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt muvɪŋ fæst, ən ðə sɛtlɝz fɔɹdʒd əhɛd sloʊli bʌt stɛɾəli.

The road was a broad highway, a major avenue of trade, wide enough for five or six wagons abreast uncrowded, with a surface of dirt and clay that hundreds of years of use had packed nearly as hard as the occasional ancient paving stone that stuck an edge or corner inches into the air. Mat and Egeanin hurried across to the verge on the other side with Noal dogging their heels, between a merchant's train rumbling toward the city, guarded by a scar-faced woman and ten hard-eyed men in leather vests covered with metal discs, and a string of the settlers' oddly shaped wagons, rising to peaks at the ends, that were heading north, some pulled by horses or mules, others by oxen. Clustered between the wagons, barefoot boys used switches to herd four-horned goats with long black hair and big, dewlapped white cows. One man at the rear of the wagons, in baggy blue breeches and a round red cap, was leading a massive hump-backed bull by a thick cord tied to a ring in its nose. Except for his clothes, he could have been from the Two Rivers. He eyed Mat and the others, walking in the same direction, as if he might speak, then shook his head and plodded on without looking at them again. Contending with Mat's limp, they were not moving fast, and the settlers forged ahead slowly but steadily.

hʌntʃ-ʃoʊldɝɾ ən klʌtʃɪŋ ðə skɑɹf bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn wɪð əɹ fɹi hænd, ɛdʒiənɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ ən lusən fɪŋɡɝz ðət hæd bɪɡʌn tə ɡɹɪp mæts saɪɾ ɔlmoʊs peɪnfəli. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə fɑɹmɝz dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ bæk əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ɹɛɾi tə tʃeɪs æftɝ ɪm ən bɑks ɪz ɪɹz ən ɪz bʊlz. ɪf ðət wɝ nɑt bæɾ ɪnʌf, wʌns ðə fɑɹmɝ wɑz twɛnti əɹ soʊ peɪsɪz əweɪ, ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ skaʊl tə ə kʌmpəni ʌv sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz mɑɹtʃɪŋ daʊn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹoʊɾ əɾ ə peɪs ðət wəd sun oʊvɝteɪk ðə sɛtlɝz, pɝhæps tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɪn ə kɑləm fɔɹ əbɹɛs fɑloʊd baɪ ə mɑtli kəlɛkʃən ə mjul-dʒɹɔn wæɡənz kʌvɝd wɪð taɪtli læʃt kænvəs. ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹoʊd wɑz lɛft fɹi fəɹ mɪlətɛɹi tʃɹæfɪk. hæf ə dʌzən wɛl-maʊntəɾ ɔfəsɝz ɪn θɪn-plum hɛlməts ðət hɪɾ ɔl bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz ɹoʊɾ ət ðə kɑləmz hɛd, lʊkɪŋ niðɝ lɛf nɔɹ ɹaɪt, ɹɛd kloʊks spɹɛd nitli oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' kɹʌpɝz. ðə bænɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ɑn ði ɔfəsɝz' hilz wɑz mɑɹkt wɪð wʌt lʊk laɪk ə staɪlaɪz sɪlvɝ æɹoʊhɛd, əɹ meɪbi ən æŋkɝ, kɹɔs baɪ ə lɔŋ æɹoʊ ən ə dʒæɡd laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt ɪn ɡoʊld, wɪð skɹɪpt ən numɝəlz bɪloʊ ðət mæt kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ əz ɡʌsts swɛp ðə bænɝ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. ðə mɛn ɑn ðə səplaɪ wæɡənz wɔɹ dɑɹk blu koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz ən skwɛɹ ɹɛd-ænd-blu kæps, bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ ivən mɔɹ ʃoʊi ðən moʊst sintʃæn, ðɛɹ sɛɡmɛntɪɾ ɑɹmɝ stʃɹaɪpt ɪn blu bændɪɾ ət ðə bɑɾəm wɪð sɪlvɝi waɪɾ ən ɹɛd bændɪd wɪð ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ, ðɛɹ hɛlməts peɪntəɾ ɪn ɔl fɔɹ kʌlɝz soʊ ðeɪ ɹɪzɛmbəl ðə feɪsəz ə fɪɹsəm spaɪɾɝz. ə lɑɹdʒ bædʒ wɪð ði æŋkɝ  mæt θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi ən æŋkɝ  ən æɹoʊ ən laɪtnɪŋ wɑz fæsən tə ðə fɹʌn ʌv itʃ hɛlmət, ən ɛvɹi mæn ɪksɛp ði ɔfəsɝz kæɹiɾ ə dʌbəl-kɝv baʊ əɾ ɪz saɪd, wɪð ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz bɛl bælənsɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt-sɔɹd.

Hunch-shouldered and clutching the scarf beneath her chin with her free hand, Egeanin let out a breath and loosened fingers that had begun to grip Mat's side almost painfully. After a moment, she straightened and glared at the farmer's departing back as though she were ready to chase after him and box his ears and his bull's. If that were not bad enough, once the farmer was twenty or so paces away, she shifted her scowl to a company of Seanchan soldiers marching down the middle of the road at a pace that would soon overtake the settlers, perhaps two hundred men in a column four abreast followed by a motley collection of mule-drawn wagons covered with tightly lashed canvas. The middle of the road was left free for military traffic. Half a dozen well-mounted officers in thin-plumed helmets that hid all but their eyes rode at the column's head, looking neither left nor right, red cloaks spread neatly over their horses' cruppers. The banner following on the officers' heels was marked with what looked like a stylized silver arrowhead, or maybe an anchor, crossed by a long arrow and a jagged lightning bolt in gold, with script and numerals below that Mat could not make out as gusts swept the banner this way and that. The men on the supply wagons wore dark blue coats and breeches and square red-and-blue caps, but the soldiers were even more showy than most Seanchan, their segmented armor striped in blue banded at the bottom with silvery white and red banded with golden yellow, their helmets painted in all four colors so they resembled the faces of fearsome spiders. A large badge with the anchor  Mat thought it must be an anchor  and arrow and lightning was fastened to the front of each helmet, and every man except the officers carried a double-curve bow at his side, with a bristling quiver at his belt balancing a short-sword.

"ʃɪps ɑɹtʃɝz," ɛdʒiənɪn ɡɹʌmbəld, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ ət ðə soʊlʒɝz. hɝ fɹi hæn hæd lɛft əɹ skɑɹf, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl klɛntʃt ɪn ə fɪst. "tævɝn bɹɔlɝz. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz kɑz pɹɑbləmz wən ðəɹ lɛft əʃɔɹ tu lɔŋ."

"Ship's archers," Egeanin grumbled, glowering at the soldiers. Her free hand had left her scarf, but it was still clenched in a fist. "Tavern brawlers. They always cause problems when they're left ashore too long."

ðeɪ hæɾ ə wɛl-tʃɹeɪn lʊk, tə mæt. ɛniweɪ, hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə soʊlʒɝz u dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ɪn faɪts, ɪspɛʃli wən ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹʌŋk əɹ bɔɹd, ən bɔɹd soʊlʒɝz tɛndəd tə ɡɛt dʒɹʌŋk. ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maɪnd wʌndɝd haʊ fɑɹ ðoʊz baʊz wəd kæɹi, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ən æbsən θɔt. hi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɛni sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz. ɪf i hæɾ ɪz weɪ, hi wəɾ əv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɛni soʊlʒɝz ɛvɝ əɡɛn.

They had a well-trained look, to Mat. Anyway, he had never heard of soldiers who did not get in fights, especially when they were drunk or bored, and bored soldiers tended to get drunk. A corner of his mind wondered how far those bows would carry, but it was an absent thought. He wanted nothing to do with any Seanchan soldiers. If he had his way, he would have nothing to do with any soldiers ever again.

bʌɾ ɪz lʌk nɛvɝ ɹæn ðət fɑɹ, ɪt simd. feɪɾ ən lʌk wɝ dɪfɹənt, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ət moʊst, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd. ə ɡʊd kɹɔsboʊ wəɾ aʊɾɝeɪndʒ ðɛm, əɹ ɛni tu ɹɪvɝz baʊ.

But his luck never ran that far, it seemed. Fate and luck were different, unfortunately. Two hundred paces at most, he decided. A good crossbow would outrange them, or any Two Rivers bow.

"wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ə tævɝn," hi sɛd θɹu hɪz tiθ, "æn ðəɹ nɑt bɹɔlɪŋ naʊ. soʊ lɛts nɑt stɑɹt wʌn dʒʌs kəz jə wɝ əfɹeɪɾ ə fɑɹmɝ wəd spik tə ju." hɝ dʒɔ sɛt, ən ʃi ʃɑɾ ɪm ə lʊk hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə kɹæk ɪz skʌl. ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ. ʃi wɑz fɪɹfəl ʌv oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ nɪɹ ɛniwʌn u maɪt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ æksɛnt. ə waɪz pɹikɔʃən, ɪn ɪz bʊk, bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə ɡɹeɪɾ ət hɝ. "wil əv ə bænɝmən oʊvɝ hɪɹ æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz ɪf jə kip ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðɛm. wɪmən ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ ɑɹ feɪməs fəɹ biɪŋ dɪmjʊɹ," hi laɪd. wʌt kəd ʃi noʊ ʌv loʊkəl kʌstəmz?

"We're not in a tavern," he said through his teeth, "and they're not brawling now. So let's not start one just because you were afraid a farmer would speak to you." Her jaw set, and she shot him a look hard enough to crack his skull. It was the truth, though. She was fearful of opening her mouth near anyone who might recognize her accent. A wise precaution, in his book, but everything seemed to grate at her. "We'll have a bannerman over here asking questions if you keep glaring at them. Women around Ebou Dar are famous for being demure," he lied. What could she know of local customs?

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ fɹaʊn  meɪbi ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt dɪmjʊɹ mɛnt  bʌt ʃi stɑpt ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət ði ɑɹtʃɝz. ʃi dʒʌs lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə baɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə hɪt.

She gave him a sidelong frown  maybe she was trying to figure out what demure meant  but she stopped grimacing at the archers. She just looked ready to bite instead of hit.

"ðæt fɛloʊz dɑɹk əz ən æθɑn maɪɹ," noʊl mʌɾɝd æbsənli, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə pæsɪŋ soʊlʒɝz. "dɑɹk əz ə ʃɝən. bʌɾ aɪd swɛɹ hiz blu aɪz. aɪv sin ðə laɪk bɪfɔɹ, bʌt wɛɹ?" tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹʌb ɪz tɛmpəlz, hi ɔlmoʊst stʃɹʌk hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə hɛd wɪð ðə bæmbu fɪʃɪŋ poʊl, ən i tʊk ə stɛp əz ðoʊ hi mɛn tə æsk ðə fɛloʊ wɛɹ i hæd bɪn bɔɹn.

"That fellow's dark as an Atha'an Miere," Noal muttered absently, staring at the passing soldiers. "Dark as a Sharan. But I'd swear he has blue eyes. I've seen the like before, but where?" Trying to rub his temples, he almost struck himself on the head with the bamboo fishing pole, and he took a step as though he meant to ask the fellow where he had been born.

wɪð ə lɝtʃ, mæt kɑt ði oʊl mænz sliv. "wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðə ʃoʊ, noʊl. naʊ. wi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛft."

With a lurch, Mat caught the old man's sleeve. "We're going back to the show, Noal. Now. We should never have left."

"aɪ toʊl jə ðæt," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd wɪð ə ʃɑɹp nɑd.

"I told you that," Egeanin said with a sharp nod.

mæt ɡɹoʊnd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə kip wɔkɪŋ. oʊ, ɪt wɑz weɪ pæs taɪm tə bi ɡɔn. hi oʊnli hoʊpt i hæd nɑt lɛft ɪt tu leɪt.

Mat groaned, but there was nothing for it but to keep walking. Oh, it was way past time to be gone. He only hoped he had not left it too late.

tʃæptɝ tu

CHAPTER 2

tu kæptənz əbaʊt tu maɪlz nɔɹθ ə ðə sɪɾi ə waɪd blu bænɝ stʃɹɛtʃt bɪtwin tu tɔl poʊlz ɹɪpəld ɪn ðə wɪnd, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ən mæɡnɪfəsən dɪspleɪ ʌv mɑɹvəlz ən wʌndɝz ɪn bɹɪljən ɹɛd lɛɾɝz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə bi ɹɛd fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd, pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz ist. fəɹ ðoʊz əneɪbəl tə ɹid, ɪɾ ət list ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðə loʊkeɪʃən ə sʌmθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi. ðɪs wɑz ðə lɑɹdʒəs tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ɪn ðə wɝld, soʊ ðə bænɝ kleɪmd. lukə kleɪmd ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz, bʌt mæt θɔɾ i mʌs bi tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt ðæt. ðə ʃoʊz kænvəs wɔl, tɛn fit haɪ ən taɪtli pɛɡd ət ðə bɑɾəm, ɛnkloʊzd əz mʌtʃ ɡɹaʊn əz ə ɡʊd-saɪz vɪlədʒ. ðə pipəl stʃɹimɪŋ baɪ lʊk təwɔɹd ðə bænɝ kjʊɹiəsli, bʌt ðə fɑɹmɝz ən mɝtʃəns hæd ðɛɹ wɝk əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ən ðə sɛtlɝz ðɛɹ fjutʃɝ, ən nʌn tɝn əsaɪd. θɪk ɹoʊps fæsən tə poʊsts sɛɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɝ mɛn tə hɝd kɹaʊdz tə ðə waɪd, ɑɹtʃt ɛntʃɹəns dʒʌs bɪhaɪn ðə bænɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn, nɑɾ ət ðɪs aʊɝ. ʌv leɪt, fju keɪm əɾ ɛni aʊɝ.

Two Captains About two miles north of the city a wide blue banner stretched between two tall poles rippled in the wind, proclaiming Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvels and Wonders in brilliant red letters large enough to be read from the road, perhaps a hundred paces east. For those unable to read, it at least indicated the location of something out of the ordinary. This was The Largest Traveling Show in the World, so the banner claimed. Luca claimed a great many things, but Mat thought he must be telling the truth about that. The show's canvas wall, ten feet high and tightly pegged at the bottom, enclosed as much ground as a good-sized village. The people streaming by looked toward the banner curiously, but the farmers and merchants had their work ahead of them and the settlers their future, and none turned aside. Thick ropes fastened to posts set in the ground were meant to herd crowds to the wide, arched entrance just behind the banner, but there was no one waiting to get in, not at this hour. Of late, few came at any hour.

ðə fɔl ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ hæd bɹɔɾ oʊnli ə slaɪt dʒɹɑp ɪn ətɛndəns, wʌns pipəl ɹilaɪz ðə sɪɾi wəd nɑt bi luɾəd ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ əv tə fli fəɹ ðɛɹ laɪvz, bʌt wɪð ðə ɹɪtɝn, ɔl ðoʊz ʃɪps ən sɛtlɝz, nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðɛɹ kɔɪn əɡɛns mɔɹ pɹɛsɪŋ nidz. tu bʌlki mɛn, hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn kloʊks ðət maɪɾ əv kʌm fɹəm ə ɹæɡbæɡ, wɝ ɑn duɾi bɪniθ ðə bænɝ tə kip aʊɾ ɛniwʌn u wɑntəd tə pik ɝaʊnd wɪθaʊt peɪɪŋ, bʌɾ ivən ðoʊz wɝ ɪn ʃɔɹt səplaɪ, naʊədeɪz. ðə pɛɹ, wʌn wɪð ə kɹʊkəd noʊz əbʌv ə θɪk mʌstæʃ ən ði ʌðɝ mɪsɪŋ ən aɪ, wɝ skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðə dɝt, tɔsɪŋ daɪs.

The fall of Ebou Dar had brought only a slight drop in attendance, once people realized the city would not be looted and they did not have to flee for their lives, but with the Return, all those ships and settlers, nearly everyone decided to hold on to their coin against more pressing needs. Two bulky men, huddling in cloaks that might have come from a ragbag, were on duty beneath the banner to keep out anyone who wanted to peek around without paying, but even those were in short supply, nowadays. The pair, one with a crooked nose above a thick mustache and the other missing an eye, were squatting on the dirt, tossing dice.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, pɛtʃɹə ænhɪl, ðə ʃoʊz stʃɹɔŋmæn, stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tu hɔɹs-hænlɝz pleɪ, ɑɹmz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən moʊs mɛnz lɛɡz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. hi wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən mæt, bʌɾ ət lis twaɪs əz waɪd, hɪz ʃoʊldɝz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðə hɛvi blu koʊɾ ɪz waɪf meɪɾ ɪm wɛɹ əɡɛns ðə koʊld. pɛtʃɹə simd ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ðə dɪsɪŋ, bʌt ðə mæn dɪd nɑt ɡæmbəl, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz pɪtʃɪŋ pɛniz. hi ən ɪz waɪf, klɛɹin, ə dɔɡ tʃɹeɪnɝ, seɪvd ɛvɹi kɔɪn ðeɪ kəd spɛɹ, ən pɛtʃɹə niɾəd smɔl ɪkskjus tə tɔk ət lɛŋθ əbaʊt ði ɪn ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə baɪ wʌn deɪ. ivən mɔɹ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ, klɛɹin wɑz əɾ ɪz saɪd, ɛnvɛləpt ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk ən əpɛɹənli əz əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðə ɡeɪmɪŋ əz hi.

Surprisingly, Petra Anhill, the show's strongman, stood watching the two horse-handlers play, arms larger than most men's legs folded across his chest. He was shorter than Mat, but at least twice as wide, his shoulders straining the heavy blue coat his wife made him wear against the cold. Petra seemed engrossed in the dicing, but the man did not gamble, not so much as pitching pennies. He and his wife, Clarine, a dog trainer, saved every coin they could spare, and Petra needed small excuse to talk at length about the inn they intended to buy one day. Even more surprising, Clarine was at his side, enveloped in a dark cloak and apparently as absorbed in the gaming as he.

pɛtʃɹə ɡlænst wɛɹəli oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪndə ðə kæmp wən i sɔ mæt ən ɛdʒiənɪn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɑɹm-ɪn-ɑɹm, wɪtʃ meɪd mæt fɹaʊn. pipəl lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz wɑz nɛvɝ ɡʊd. klɛɹinz plʌmp bɹaʊn feɪs bɹoʊk ɪndə ə wɔɹm smaɪl, ðoʊ. laɪk moʊst wɪmən ɪn ðə ʃoʊ, ʃi θɔɾ i ən ɛdʒiənɪn wɝ ɹoʊmæntɪk. ðə bɛnt-noʊz hɔɹs-hænlɝ, ə hɛvi-ʃoʊldɝd tɛɹən neɪm kɑl, lɪɹɾ əz i skupt ʌp ðə weɪdʒɝ, ə fju kɑpɝz. noʊ wʌn bʌt doʊmən kəd si ɛdʒiənɪn əz pɹɪɾi, bʌt tə səm fulz, noʊbɪləɾi bɪstoʊd bjuɾi. əɹ mʌni dɪd, ən ə noʊbəlwʊmən mʌs bi ɹɪtʃ. ə fju θɔɾ ɛni noʊbəlwʊmən u əbændən əɹ hʌzbən fəɹ ðə laɪks ə mæt kɔθən maɪt bi oʊpən tə livɪŋ hɪm, tu, ən bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ mʌni wɪð hɝ. ðət wɑz ðə stɔɹi mæt ən ði ʌðɝz hæd pʊɾ ɝaʊn tə ɪkspleɪn waɪ ðeɪ wɝ haɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn: ə kɹuəl hʌzbən ən ə lʌvɝz' flaɪt. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd hɝd ðət sɔɹɾ ə teɪl, fɹəm ɡlimən əɹ bʊks ɪf sɛldəm ɹil laɪf, ɔfən ɪnʌf tə æksɛpt ɪt. kɑl kɛpt ɪz hɛd daʊn, ðoʊ. ɛdʒiənɪn - laɪlwɪn - hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔn əɹ bɛl naɪf ɑn ə sɔɹd-dʒʌɡəlɝ, ə tu-hænsəm fɛloʊ hu hæd bɪn oʊvɝli sədʒɛstɪv ɪn æskɪŋ əɹ tə ʃɛɹ ə kʌp ʌv waɪn ɪn ɪz wæɡən, ən noʊ wʌn daʊɾɪd ʃi wʊɾə juz ðə bleɪɾ ɪf i hæd pɹɛst ɪz suɾ ən ɪntʃ fɝðɝ.

Petra glanced warily over his shoulder into the camp when he saw Mat and Egeanin approaching arm-in-arm, which made Mat frown. People looking over their shoulders was never good. Clarine's plump brown face broke into a warm smile, though. Like most women in the show, she thought he and Egeanin were romantic. The bent-nosed horse-handler, a heavy-shouldered Tairen named Col, leered as he scooped up the wager, a few coppers. No one but Domon could see Egeanin as pretty, but to some fools, nobility bestowed beauty. Or money did, and a noblewoman must be rich. A few thought any noblewoman who abandoned her husband for the likes of Mat Cauthon might be open to leaving him, too, and bringing her money with her. That was the story Mat and the others had put around to explain why they were hiding from the Seanchan: a cruel husband and a lovers' flight. Everyone had heard that sort of tale, from gleemen or books if seldom real life, often enough to accept it. Col kept his head down, though. Egeanin - Leilwin - had already drawn her belt knife on a sword-juggler, a too-handsome fellow who had been overly suggestive in asking her to share a cup of wine in his wagon, and no one doubted she would have used the blade if he had pressed his suit an inch further.

əz sun əz mæt ɹitʃt ðə stʃɹɔŋmæn, pɛtʃɹə sɛd kwaɪətli, "ðɛɹ ɑɹ sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz tɔkɪŋ tə lukə, əbaʊt twɛnti ʌv ðɛm. ði ɔfəsɝz tɔkɪŋ wɪð hɪm, listwaɪz." hi dɪd nɑt saʊn fɹaɪɾənd, bʌt wɝi kɹist ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ən i leɪɾ ə pɹətɛktɪv hæn ɑn ɪz waɪfs ʃoʊldɝ. klɛɹinz smaɪl feɪɾəd, ən ʃi ɹeɪzd wʌn hæn tə ɹɛst ətɑp hɪz. ðeɪ tʃɹʌstɪd lukəs dʒʌdʒmənt, æftɝ ə fæʃən, jɛt ðeɪ nu ðə ɹɪsk ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ. əɹ θɔt ðeɪ dɪd. ðə ɹɪsk ðeɪ bɪlivd ɪn wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf. "wʌt də ðeɪ wɑnt?" ɛdʒiənɪn dɪmændəd, pʊʃɪŋ fɹi ʌv mæt, bɪfɔɹ i kəd kɹæk ɪz tiθ. ɪn fækt, noʊ wʌn weɪɾəd fəɹ hɪm. "hoʊl ðiz fəɹ mi," noʊl sɛd, hændɪŋ ɪz poʊl ən bæskət tə ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn, hu ɡeɪpt ʌp ət hɪm. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, noʊl slɪpt ə nɑbəli hæn bɪniθ ɪz koʊt, wɛɹ i kɛp tu lɔŋbleɪɾɪd naɪvz. "kæn wi ɹitʃ əɹ hɔɹsəz?" hi æsk pɛtʃɹə. ðə stʃɹɔŋmæn aɪɾ ɪm daʊtfəli. mæt wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn ənʃʊɹ wɛðɝ noʊl stɪl pəzɛst ɔl ɪz wɪts.

As soon as Mat reached the strongman, Petra said quietly, "There are Seanchan soldiers talking to Luca, about twenty of them. The officer's talking with him, leastwise." He did not sound frightened, but worry creased his forehead, and he laid a protective hand on his wife's shoulder. Clarine's smile faded, and she raised one hand to rest atop his. They trusted Lucas judgment, after a fashion, yet they knew the risk they were running. Or thought they did. The risk they believed in was bad enough. "What do they want?" Egeanin demanded, pushing free of Mat, before he could crack his teeth. In fact, no one waited for him. "Hold these for me," Noal said, handing his pole and basket to the one-eyed man, who gaped up at him. Straightening, Noal slipped a knobbly hand beneath his coat, where he kept two longbladed knives. "Can we reach our horses?" he asked Petra. The strongman eyed him doubtfully. Mat was not the only one unsure whether Noal still possessed all his wits.

"ðeɪ doʊn sim ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn sɝtʃɪŋ," klɛɹin sɛd heɪstəli, meɪkɪŋ ə hɪn ʌv ə kɝtsi tə ɛdʒiənɪn. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz səpoʊz tə pɹitɛn mæt ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə ʃoʊ, bʌt fju mænədʒ tə kæɹi ɪɾ ɔf wɪð ɛdʒiənɪn. "ði ɔfəsɝz bɪn ɪn lukəz wæɡən fəɹ ə ɡʊd hæf-aʊɝ, bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz əv bɪn stændɪŋ baɪ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɔl ðət taɪm."

"They don't seem interested in searching," Clarine said hastily, making a hint of a curtsy to Egeanin. Everyone was supposed to pretend Mat and the others were part of the show, but few managed to carry it off with Egeanin. "The officer's been in Luca's wagon for a good half-hour, but the soldiers have been standing by their horses all that time."

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɹ hɪɹ əbaʊt ju," pɛtʃɹə æɾəd ɹɪspɛkfəli. əɡɛn, tə ɛdʒiənɪn. waɪ ʃəɾ i bi dɪfɹənt? pɹɑbli pɹæktəsɪŋ tə wɛlkəm noʊbəlz tə ðəɾ ɪn. "wi dʒʌs dɪdnt wɑn jə tə bi sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ wɝid, siɪŋ ðɛm. aɪm ʃʊɹ lukə wɪl sɛn əm ɔf wɪð noʊ tʃɹʌbəl." dɪspaɪɾ ɪz toʊn, ðə kɹisɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. moʊs mɛn bɪkeɪm əpsɛɾ ɪf ðɛɹ waɪvz ɹæn ɔf, ən ə noʊbəlmən kəd meɪk ʌðɝz bɛɹ ðə bɹʌn ə hɪz aɪɹ. ə tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ, stʃɹeɪnʒɝz dʒʌs pæsɪŋ θɹu, meɪɾ ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli izi tɑɹɡət wɪθaʊɾ æɾəd kɑmpləkeɪʃənz. "ju doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɛnibəɾi tɔkɪŋ aʊɾ ə tɝn, maɪ leɪɾi." ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz, pɛtʃɹə æɾəd, "dʌz ʃi, kɑl?" bɛnt-noʊz ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, hɪz aɪz ɑn ðə daɪs i wɑz baʊnsɪŋ ɑn ɪz pɑm. hi wɑz ə bɪɡ mæn, bʌt nɑɾ əz bɪɡ əz pɛtʃɹə, ən ðə stʃɹɔŋmæn kəd stʃɹeɪɾən hɔɹsʃuz wɪð ɪz bɛɹ hænz.

"I don't think they're here about you," Petra added respectfully. Again, to Egeanin. Why should he be different? Probably practicing to welcome nobles to that inn. "We just didn't want you to be surprised or worried, seeing them. I'm sure Luca will send them off with no trouble." Despite his tone, the creases remained in his forehead. Most men became upset if their wives ran off, and a nobleman could make others bear the brunt of his ire. A traveling show, strangers just passing through, made a particularly easy target without added complications. "You don't have to worry about anybody talking out of turn, my Lady." Glancing at the horse handlers, Petra added, "Does she, Col?" Bent-nose shook his head, his eyes on the dice he was bouncing on his palm. He was a big man, but not as big as Petra, and the strongman could straighten horseshoes with his bare hands.

"ɛvɹibɑɾi laɪks ə tʃæns tə spɪɾ ɑn ə noʊbəlz buts naʊ ən ðɛn," ðə wʌn-aɪd fɛloʊ mʌmbəld, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə bæskəɾ ə fɪʃ. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl ən waɪd-ʃoʊldɝɾ əz kɑl, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz ɔl lɛðɝi ɹɪŋkəlz, ən i hæɾ ivən fjuɝ tiθ ðən noʊl. ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɛdʒiənɪn, hi dʌkt ɪz hɛɾ ən æɾəd, "bɛɡɪŋ jəɹ pɑɹɾən, leɪɾi. 'saɪdz, ðɪs weɪ wi ɔl ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn, wɪtʃ ðəɹ eɪn bɪn mʌtʃ ə leɪtli. ɹaɪt, kɑl? ɛnibəɾi tɔks, ðɛm sintʃænəl teɪk əs ɔl ʌp, meɪbi hæŋ əs laɪk ðeɪ dɪɾ əm si foʊk. əɹ pʊɾ əs tə wɝk klinɪŋ əm kənælz ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɑɹbɝ." hɔɹs hænlɝz dɪd wʌtɛvɝ niɾəd duɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ʃoʊ, fɹəm mʌkɪŋ ðə hɔɹslaɪnz ən klinɪŋ ænəməlz' keɪdʒɪz tə ɪɹɛktɪŋ ən teɪkɪŋ daʊn ðə kænvəs wɔl, bʌɾ i ʃʌɾɝəd əz ðoʊ dɪɡɪŋ aʊt sɪltɪd kənælz ɪn ðə ɹæhəd wɑz ə wɝs pɹɑspɛk ðən hæŋɪŋ.

"Everybody likes a chance to spit on a noble's boots now and then," the one-eyed fellow mumbled, peering into the basket of fish. He was almost as tall and wide-shouldered as Col, but his face was all leathery wrinkles, and he had even fewer teeth than Noal. Glancing at Egeanin, he ducked his head and added, "Begging your pardon, Lady. 'Sides, this way we all get a little coin, which there ain't been much of lately. Right, Col? Anybody talks, them Seanchan'll take us all up, maybe hang us like they did them Sea Folk. Or put us to work cleaning them canals the other side of the harbor." Horse handlers did whatever needed doing around the show, from mucking the horselines and cleaning animals' cages to erecting and taking down the canvas wall, but he shuddered as though digging out silted canals in the Rahad was a worse prospect than hanging.

"dɪɾ aɪ seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt tɔkɪŋ?" kɑl pɹətɛstəd, spɹɛɾɪŋ ɪz hænz. "aɪ dʒʌst æsk haʊ lɔŋ wɝ gɑnə sɪt hɪɹ, ðæts ɔl. aɪ dʒʌst æskt wən wɝ gɑnə si səm ə ðɪs kɔɪn." "wi sɪt hɪɹ əz lɔŋ əz aɪ seɪ sɪt." ɪt wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl haʊ hɑɹɾ ɛdʒiənɪn kəd meɪk ðət dʒɹɔl saʊnd wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs, laɪk ə bleɪd slaɪɾɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðə skæbɝd. "ju si jəɹ kɔɪn wən wi ɹitʃ əɹ dɛstəneɪʃən.

"Did I say anything about talking?" Col protested, spreading his hands. "I just asked how long we're going to sit here, that's all. I just asked when we're going to see some of this coin." "We sit here as long as I say sit." It was remarkable how hard Egeanin could make that drawl sound without raising her voice, like a blade sliding free of the scabbard. "You see your coin when we reach our destination.

ðəɹ wɪl bi ə lɪɾəl sʌmθɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə fəɹ ðoʊz u sɝv mi feɪθfəli. ən ə koʊld ɡɹeɪv fəɹ ɛniwʌn u θɪŋks ɑn bɪtʃɹeɪəl." kɑl pʊld ɪz mʌtʃ-pætʃt kloʊk taɪɾ ən waɪɾənd ɪz aɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɪndɪɡnənt, əɹ meɪbi ɪnəsənt, bʌɾ i dʒʌst əpɪɹd tə bi hoʊpɪŋ ʃi wəd kʌm kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə fɪltʃ əɹ pɝs.

There will be a little something extra for those who serve me faithfully. And a cold grave for anyone who thinks on betrayal." Col pulled his much-patched cloak tight and widened his eyes trying to look indignant, or maybe innocent, but he just appeared to be hoping she would come close enough for him to filch her purse.

mæt ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ðət wɑz ɪz ɡoʊld ʃi wɑz pɹɑməsɪŋ wɪð sətʃ ə fɹi hænd.

Mat ground his teeth. For one thing, that was his gold she was promising with such a free hand.

ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn, bʌt nɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ ðɪs. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ əɡɛn.

She had her own, but not near enough for this. More importantly, she was trying to take charge again.

laɪt, ɪksɛp fəɹ hɪm, ʃi wəd stɪl bi ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ skimɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðə sikɝz, ɪf nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi biɪŋ pʊt tə ðə kwɛstʃən.

Light, except for him, she would still be in Ebou Dar scheming to avoid the Seekers, if not already being put to the question.

ɪksɛp fəɹ hɪm, ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əv θɔɾ ə steɪɪŋ kloʊs tə ɛbu dɑɹ tə θɹoʊ ɔf pɝsut, əɹ faʊn ə haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs wɪð lukəz ʃoʊ. bʌt waɪ wɝ soʊlʒɝz ðɛɹ? ðə sintʃæn wʊɾə sɛn ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, ə θaʊzənd, fəɹ ə veɪɡ səspɪʃən ə tuɑnz pɹɛzəns. ɪf ðeɪ səspɛktəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. . . .

Except for him, she would never have thought of staying close to Ebou Dar to throw off pursuit, or found a hiding place with Luca's show. But why were soldiers there? The Seanchan would have sent a hundred men, a thousand, for a vague suspicion of Tuon's presence. If they suspected the Aes Sedai. . . .

noʊ! pɛtʃɹə ən klɛɹin dɪd nɑt noʊ ðeɪ wɝ hɛlpɪŋ haɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðeɪ wʊɾə mɛnʃən sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd nɑt bi hʌntɪŋ sɪstɝz wɪθaʊt ðɛm. hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə fɑkshɛd θɹu hɪz koʊt. hi wɔɹ ðət weɪkɪŋ ən slipɪŋ, ən ɪt maɪt ɡɪv ɪm ə lɪɾəl wɔɹnɪŋ.

No! Petra and Clarine did not know they were helping hide Aes Sedai, but they would have mentioned sul'dam and damane, and the soldiers would not be hunting sisters without them. He fingered the foxhead through his coat. He wore that waking and sleeping, and it might give him a little warning.

hi nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd tʃɹaɪɪŋ fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz kɑl ən ə dʌzən mɔɹ laɪk ɪm wəd ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə sintʃæn bɪfɔɹ i wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ə saɪt. ðeɪ hæd noʊ pɝtɪkjəlɝ ænəmɑsəɾi təwɔɹɾ ɪm əɹ ɛdʒiənɪn ðəɾ i nu - ivən ɹumən, ðə sɔɹdʒʌɡəlɝ, sim tə hæv sɛɾəld ɪn hæpəli wɪð ə kəntɔɹʃənəs neɪmd ɑdʒɹiə - bʌt səm foʊks wəd nɑt ɹɪzɪs ðə tɛmteɪʃən ʌv ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɡoʊld, iðɝ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, noʊ wɔɹnɪŋ daɪs tʌmbəld ɪn ɪz hɛd. ən ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɪnsaɪd ðoʊz kænvəs wɔlz i kəd nɑt liv bɪhaɪnd.

He never considered trying for the horses, and not just because Col and a dozen more like him would go running to the Seanchan before he was well out of sight. They had no particular animosity toward him or Egeanin that he knew - even Rumann, the swordjuggler, seemed to have settled in happily with a contortionist named Adria - but some folks would not resist the temptation of a little more gold, either. In any case, no warning dice tumbled in his head. And there were people inside those canvas walls he could not leave behind.

"ɪf ðəɹ nɑt sɝtʃɪŋ, ðən wɪv nʌθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt," hi sɛd kɑnfəɾəntli. "bʌt θæŋks fəɹ ðə wɔɹnɪŋ, pɛtʃɹə. aɪv nɛvɝ laɪk sɝpɹaɪzəz." ðə stʃɹɔŋmæn meɪɾ ə smɔl dʒɛstʃɝ əz ɪf tə seɪ ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ən klɛɹin lʊkt ət mæt əz ðoʊ stɑɹɾəld tə faɪn ɪm ðɛɹ. ivən kɑl ən ðə wʌn-aɪd laʊt blɪŋkt ət hɪm. ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt tə stɑp ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ɪz tiθ əɡɛn. "aɪl dʒʌst wɑndɝ nɪɹ lukəz wæɡən ən si wʌɾ aɪ kən si. leɪ wʌn wɪn, jə ən noʊl faɪn oʊlvɝ ən steɪ wɪð hɪm." ðeɪ laɪk ðə bɔɪ, ɛvɹiwʌn dɪd, ən ðət wəd kip əm aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɹ. hi kəɾ ivzdʒɹɑp bɛɾɝ əloʊn. ən ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə ɹʌn, meɪbi ɛdʒiənɪn ən noʊl kəd hɛlp ɡɛt ðə bɔɪ aʊt, ət list. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt dɪd nɑt kʌm tə ðæt. hi kəd si nʌθɪŋ bʌt dɪzæstɝ ɪn ɪt.

"If they're not searching, then we have nothing to worry about," he said confidently. "But thanks for the warning, Petra. I've never liked surprises." The strongman made a small gesture as if to say it was nothing, but Egeanin and Clarine looked at Mat as though startled to find him there. Even Col and the one-eyed lout blinked at him. It took an effort to stop short of gritting his teeth again. "I'll just wander near Luca's wagon and see what I can see. Lei 1 win, you and Noal find Olver and stay with him." They liked the boy, everyone did, and that would keep them out of his hair. He could eavesdrop better alone. And if they had to run, maybe Egeanin and Noal could help get the boy out, at least. The Light send it did not come to that. He could see nothing but disaster in it.

"wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz noʊbɑdi laɪvz fɝɛvɝ," noʊl saɪd, ɹitʃɹivɪŋ ɪz bæmbu poʊl ən bæskət.

"Well, I suppose nobody lives forever," Noal sighed, retrieving his bamboo pole and basket.

bɝn hɪm, bʌt ðə fɛloʊ kəd meɪk ə kɑlɪki ɡoʊt sim tʃɪɹfəl! pɛtʃɹəz fɹaʊn sɝɾənli dipənd.

Burn him, but the fellow could make a colicky goat seem cheerful! Petra's frown certainly deepened.

mɛɹid mɛn ɔlweɪz sim tə bi wɝid, wʌn ɹizən mæt wɑz ɪn noʊ hɝi hɪmsɛlf. əz noʊl vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə kænvəs wɔl, ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn wɑtʃt ðə fɪʃ ɡoʊ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. hi əpɪɹd tə bi ənʌðɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə fʊl sɛɾ ʌv wɪts. hi pɹɑbli hæɾ ə waɪf sʌmwɛɹ.

Married men always seemed to be worried, one reason Mat was in no hurry himself. As Noal vanished around the corner of the canvas wall, the one-eyed man watched the fish go regretfully. He appeared to be another without a full set of wits. He probably had a wife somewhere.

mæt pʊld ɪz kæp ɔlmoʊs daʊn tə hɪz aɪz. stɪl noʊ daɪs. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ə haʊ mɛni taɪmz i hæd nɪɹli hæɾ ɪz θɹoʊt slɪɾ əɹ ɪz skʌl splɪt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daɪs. bʌt ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni ɹil deɪnʒɝ. ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ wʊd. hi hæd nɑt teɪkən θɹi stɛps ɪnsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹəns bɪfɔɹ ɛdʒiənɪn kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm ən slɪpt əɹ ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. hi stɑpt ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks, aɪɪŋ əɹ bɑlfəli. ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪɾ ɪz ɔɹɾɝz ðə weɪ ə tʃɹaʊt fɔt ðə hʊk, bʌt ðɪs wɛn bɪɑn stʌbɝn. "wʌt dʒju θɪŋk jəɹ duɪŋ? wʌɾ ɪf ðɪs sintʃæn ɔfəsɝ ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəz ju?" ðət simd əz laɪkli əz taɪlɪn hɝsɛlf wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə ʃoʊ, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt meɪk əɹ liv wɑz wɝθ ɡɹæbɪŋ.

Mat pulled his cap almost down to his eyes. Still no dice. He tried not to think of how many times he had nearly had his throat slit or his skull split without any dice. But surely they would have been there if there was any real danger. Of course they would. He had not taken three steps inside the entrance before Egeanin caught up to him and slipped her arm around his waist. He stopped in his tracks, eyeing her balefully. She resisted his orders the way a trout fought the hook, but this went beyond stubborn. "What do you think you're doing? What if this Seanchan officer recognizes you?" That seemed as likely as Tylin herself walking into the show, but anything that might make her leave was worth grabbing.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðə tʃænsəz ðɪs fɛloʊ ɪz ɛniwʌn aɪ noʊ?" ʃi skɔft. "aɪ doʊn əv . . ." hɝ feɪs twɪstəd fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, "dɪdn əv . . . mɛni fɹɛnz ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən, ən nʌn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ." ʃi tʌtʃt ən ɛn ə ðə blæk wɪɡ oʊvɝ əɹ bʊzəm. "ɛniweɪ, ɪn ðɪs, maɪ oʊn mʌðɝ wʊdn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi." hɝ vɔɪs tɝn blik təwɔɹd ði ɛnd.

"What are the chances this fellow is anyone I know?" she scoffed. "I don't have . . ." her face twisted for an instant, "didn't have . . . many friends this side of the ocean, and none in Ebou Dar." She touched an end of the black wig over her bosom. "Anyway, in this, my own mother wouldn't recognize me." Her voice turned bleak toward the end.

hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃɪp ə tuθ ɪf i kɛpt ɑn klɛntʃɪŋ ɪz dʒɔ. stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð əɹ wəd bi wɝs ðən jusləs, bʌt ðə weɪ ʃi hæd stɛɹɾ ət ðoʊz sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz wɑz fɹɛʃ ɪn ɪz maɪnd. "doʊnt ɡlɛɹ əɾ ɛnibəɾi," hi wɔɹn hɝ. "doʊn ivən lʊk əɾ ɛnibəɾi."

He was going to chip a tooth if he kept on clenching his jaw. Standing there arguing with her would be worse than useless, but the way she had stared at those Seanchan soldiers was fresh in his mind. "Don't glare at anybody," he warned her. "Don't even look at anybody."

"ɪm ə dɪmjʊɹ ɛbu dɑɹi wʊmən." ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ə tʃælənʒ.

"I'm a demure Ebou Dari woman." She made it sound a challenge.

"ju kən də ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ." ʃi meɪd ðəɾ ɪndə ə wɔɹnɪŋ. laɪt! wən ə wʊmən wɑz nɑt meɪkɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ smuð, ʃi meɪd θɪŋz vɛɹi ɹʌf ɪndid, ən ɛdʒiənɪn nɛvɝ meɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ smuð. hi wɑz dɛfənətli ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə tʃɪpɪŋ ə tuθ. bɪɑn ði ɛntʃɹəns, ðə ʃoʊz meɪn stʃɹit miændɝɾ əmʌŋ wæɡənz laɪk ðoʊz ðə tɪŋkɝz juzd, lɪɾəl haʊsəz ɑn wilz wɪð ðə wæɡən ʃæfs lɪftəɾ əɡɛns ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz' sits, ən wɔl tɛns ɔfən əz lɑɹdʒ əz smɔl haʊsəz. moʊst ə ðə wæɡənz wɝ bɹaɪtli peɪntəd, ɛvɹi ʃeɪɾ ə ɹɛɾ əɹ ɡɹin, jɛloʊ əɹ blu, ən mɛni ʌv ðə tɛns wɝ dʒʌst əz kʌlɝfəl, ə fju ivən stʃɹaɪpt. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wʊɾən plætfɔɹmz, wɛɹ ɛntɝteɪnɝz kəd pɝfɔɹm, stʊd bɪsaɪd ðə stʃɹit, ðɛɹ kʌlɝd bʌntɪŋ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə lʊk ə bɪt ɡɹʌbi.

"You can do all the talking." She made that into a warning. Light! When a woman was not making everything smooth, she made things very rough indeed, and Egeanin never made anything smooth. He was definitely in danger of chipping a tooth. Beyond the entrance, the show's main street meandered among wagons like those the Tinkers used, little houses on wheels with the wagon shafts lifted against the drivers' seats, and walled tents often as large as small houses. Most of the wagons were brightly painted, every shade of red or green, yellow or blue, and many of the tents were just as colorful, a few even striped. Here and there wooden platforms, where entertainers could perform, stood beside the street, their colored bunting beginning to look a bit grubby.

ðə bɹɔɾ ɪkspæns ə dɝt, nɪɹ θɝɾi peɪsɪz waɪɾ ən biɾən flæt baɪ θaʊzənz ə fit, ɹɪli wɑz ə stʃɹit, wʌn ə sɛvɹəl ðət waʊn θɹu ðə ʃoʊ. ðə wɪnd wɪpt əweɪ feɪnt ɡɹeɪ stʃɹimɝz ə smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɪn tʃɪmniz ðət stʌk fɹəm ʌp fɹəm ðə ɹufs ə ðə wæɡənz, ən fɹəm səm tɛns. moʊst ə ðə ʃoʊfoʊk wɝ pɹɑbli ət bɹɛkfəst ɪf nɑt stɪl ɪn bɛd. ðeɪ ɹoʊz leɪt, əz ə ɹul - ə ɹul mæt əpɹuvd - ən noʊ wʌn wəd wɑnə it sɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ə kʊk faɪɝ aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðɪs koʊld. ði oʊnli pɝsən i sɔ wɑz ɑlʌdʒɹə, ðə slivz ə hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin dʒɹɛs pʊʃt ʌp əɹ fɹɑɹmz, ɡɹaɪndɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ə bɹɑnz mɔɹɾɝ ən pɛsəl ɑn ə teɪbəl ðət foʊldəd daʊn fɹəm ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ vɪvəd blu wæɡən, dʒʌst ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ɑn wʌn ə ðə nɛɹoʊɝ saɪd stʃɹits. ɪntɛn ɑn əɹ wɝk, ðə slɛndɝ tæɹɑbənɝ dɪd nɑt si ɛdʒiənɪn ən mæt. hi kəd nɑt hɛlp lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, ðoʊ. wɪð əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ ɪn θɪn, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz ðət hʌŋ tə hɝ weɪst, ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz pɹɑbli ðə moʊst ɪɡzɑɾɪk ə lukəz mɑɹvəlz. hi ædvɝtaɪzd əɹ əz ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ, ən ənlaɪk mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ pɝfɔɹmɝz ən mɑɹvəlz, ʃi ɹɪli wɑz wʌt lukə kleɪmd, ðoʊ lukə pɹɑbli dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt hɪmsɛlf. mæt wʌndɝd wʌt ʃi wɑz ɡɹaɪndɪŋ. ən wɛðɝ ɪt maɪɾ ɪksploʊd. ʃi hæd pɹɑməs tə ɹɪvil ðə sikɹəɾ ə faɪɹwɝks ɪf i kəɾ ænsɝ ə ɹɪɾəl, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt faʊn ə ɡlɪmɝ, soʊ fɑɹ. hi wʊd, ðoʊ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ɛdʒiənɪn poʊkt ə hɑɹd fɪŋɡɝ ɪndə hɪz ɹɪbz. "wɝ səpoʊz tə bi lʌvɝz, əz jə kip ɹimaɪndɪŋ mi," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "huz gɑnə bɪliv ɪɾ ɪf jə stɛɹ ət ðət wʊmən əz ðoʊ jəɹ hʌŋɡɹi?" mæt ɡɹɪn læsɪviəsli. "aɪ ɔlweɪz lʊk ət pɹɪɾi wɪmən, hævən jə noʊɾəst.-" ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ hɛd skɑɹf wɪð ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ vɪɡɝ ðən juʒəwəl, ʃi ɡeɪv ə dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ɡɹʌnt, ən i wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd. hɝ pɹuɾɪʃ stʃɹik keɪm ɪn hændi naʊ ən ðɛn. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ɑn ðə ɹʌn fəɹ əɹ laɪf, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl sintʃæn, ən ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi nu mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɪm ðən i laɪkt. hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə tʃɹʌst əɹ wɪð ɔl ə hɪz sikɹəts. ivən ðə wʌnz i dɪd nɑt noʊ jɛt.

The broad expanse of dirt, near thirty paces wide and beaten flat by thousands of feet, really was a street, one of several that wound through the show. The wind whipped away faint gray streamers of smoke rising from the tin chimneys that stuck from up from the roofs of the wagons, and from some tents. Most of the showfolk were probably at breakfast if not still in bed. They rose late, as a rule - a rule Mat approved - and no one would want to eat sitting around a cook fire outside in this cold. The only person he saw was Aludra, the sleeves of her dark green dress pushed up her forearms, grinding something with a bronze mortar and pestle on a table that folded down from the side of her vivid blue wagon, just around the corner on one of the narrower side streets. Intent on her work, the slender Taraboner did not see Egeanin and Mat. He could not help looking at her, though. With her dark hair in thin, beaded braids that hung to her waist, Aludra was probably the most exotic of Luca's marvels. He advertised her as an Illuminator, and unlike many of the other performers and marvels, she really was what Luca claimed, though Luca probably did not believe it himself. Mat wondered what she was grinding. And whether it might explode. She had promised to reveal the secret of fireworks if he could answer a riddle, but he had not found a glimmer, so far. He would, though. One way or another. Egeanin poked a hard finger into his ribs. "We're supposed to be lovers, as you keep reminding me," she growled. "Who's going to believe it if you stare at that woman as though you're hungry?" Mat grinned lasciviously. "I always look at pretty women, haven't you noticed.-" Adjusting her head scarf with a little more vigor than usual, she gave a disparaging grunt, and he was satisfied. Her prudish streak came in handy now and then. Egeanin was on the run for her life, but she was still Seanchan, and she already knew more about him than he liked. He was not about to trust her with all of his secrets. Even the ones he did not know yet.

lukəz wæɡən sæɾ ɪn ðə vɛɹi mɪɾəl ə ðə ʃoʊz kæmp, ðə moʊs feɪvɝd pəzɪʃən, əz fɑɹ əz pɑsəbəl fɹəm ðə smɛlz ə ði ænəməl keɪdʒɪz ən hɔɹslaɪnz sɪtʃueɪɾɪd əlɔŋ ðə kænvəs wɔlz. ðə wæɡən wɑz ɡɛɹɪʃ ivən kəmpɛɹd tə ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə ʃoʊ, ə ɹɛɾ ən blu θɪŋ ðət ʃoʊn laɪk ðə faɪnəs lækɹwɝk, ɛvɹi sɝfəs spɑɾəd wɪð ɡoʊldən kɑməts ən stɑɹz. ðə feɪzəz ə ðə mun, ɪn sɪlvɝ, ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn dʒʌs bɪloʊ ðə ɹuflaɪn. ivən ðə tɪn tʃɪmni wɑz peɪntəɾ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blu ɹɪŋz. eɪ tɪŋkɝ wəɾ əv blʌʃt. tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən tu ɹæŋks ə hɛlməɾɪd sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz stʊd stɪfli bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ɡɹin-tæsɛld lænsɪz slæntəɾ əɾ ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm æŋɡəl. wʌn ə ðə mɛn hɛl ðə ɹeɪnz ʌv ən ɛkstʃɹə maʊnt, ə faɪn dʌn ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð stʃɹɔŋ hɔntʃɪz ən ɡʊɾ æŋkəlz. ðə soʊlʒɝz'

Luca's wagon sat in the very middle of the show's camp, the most favored position, as far as possible from the smells of the animal cages and horselines situated along the canvas walls. The wagon was garish even compared to the others in the show, a red and blue thing that shone like the finest lacquerwork, every surface spotted with golden comets and stars. The phases of the moon, in silver, ran all the way around just below the roofline. Even the tin chimney was painted in red and blue rings. A Tinker would have blushed. To one side of the wagon two ranks of helmeted Seanchan soldiers stood stiffly beside their horses, green-tasseled lances slanted at exactly the same angle. One of the men held the reins of an extra mount, a fine dun gelding with strong haunches and good ankles. The soldiers'

blu-ænd-ɡɹin ɑɹmɝ əpɪɹd dʒɹæb əlɔŋsaɪd lukəz wæɡən.

blue-and-green armor appeared drab alongside Luca's wagon.

mæt wɑz ənsɝpɹaɪz tə si hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðə sintʃæn. ə dɑɹk stɑkɪŋ kæp kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz ʃeɪv hɛd, beɪl doʊmən wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz hilz wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛnst wʌn wil ə ðə ɡɹin wæɡən ðət bɪlɔŋ tə pɛtʃɹə ən klɛɹin, əbaʊt θɝɾi peɪsɪz bɪɑn ðə soʊlʒɝz. klɛɹinz dɑɡz leɪ ʌndɝ ðə wæɡən, ə mɑtli kəlɛkʃən ə smɔlɪʃ ænəməlz slipɪŋ hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ. ðə θɪk-bɑɾid ɪliɑnɝ wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə wɪɾəl, bʌɾ ɔl i hæd pɹədust wɑz ə smɔl paɪl ə ʃeɪvɪŋz əɾ ɪz fit. mæt wɪʃt ðə fɛloʊ wəd ɡɹoʊ ə mʌstæʃ tə haɪɾ ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp əɹ ɛls ʃeɪv ɔf ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz bɪɹd. sʌmwʌn maɪt kənɛkt ən ɪliɑnɝ tə ɛdʒiənɪn. blɹɪk nɛdʒinə, ə tɔl fɛloʊ linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wæɡən əz ðoʊ kipɪŋ doʊmən kʌmpəni, hæd nɑt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd tə ɹimuv ɪz ʃaɪnɝən tɑpnɑt tə əvɔɪd sintʃæn noʊɾəs, ðoʊ hi ɹæn ə hæn oʊvɝ ðə blæk bɹɪsəl ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪz hɛɾ əbaʊɾ əz ɔfən əz ɛdʒiənɪn tʃɛkt əɹ wɪɡ. meɪbi hi ʃəd wɛɹ ə kæp. ɪn ðɛɹ dɑɹk koʊts wɪð fɹeɪd kʌfs ən wɛl-tʃɹævəl buts, boʊθ mɛn kəd pæs fəɹ ʃoʊfoʊk, meɪbi hɔɹs-hænlɝz, ɪksɛp tə ʌðɝ ʃoʊfoʊk. ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə sintʃæn waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sim nɑt tə, bʌt blɹɪk wɑz ðə mɔɹ səksɛsfəl, əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm ə wɔɹɾɝ. hɪz fʊl ətɛnʃən əpɪɹd tə bi ɑn doʊmən, ɪksɛp fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl ɡlæns ət ðə soʊlʒɝz, əz kæʒəwəl əz kəd bi. doʊmən skaʊld ət ðə sintʃæn wən i wɑz nɑt ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə lʌmp ʌv wʊɾ ɪn ɪz hænd, əz ðoʊ ɔɹɾɝɪŋ ɪt tə tɝn ɪndə ə nit kɑɹvɪŋ. ðə mæn hæd teɪkən biɪŋ sɔɪbən ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ tə hɑɹt.

Mat was unsurprised to see he was not the only one interested in the Seanchan. A dark stocking cap covering his shaved head, Bayle Domon was squatting on his heels with his back against one wheel of the green wagon that belonged to Petra and Clarine, about thirty paces beyond the soldiers. Clarine's dogs lay under the wagon, a motley collection of smallish animals sleeping huddled together. The thick-bodied Illianer was pretending to whittle, but all he had produced was a small pile of shavings at his feet. Mat wished the fellow would grow a mustache to hide his upper lip or else shave off the rest of his beard. Someone might connect an Illianer to Egeanin. Blaeric Negina, a tall fellow leaning against the wagon as though keeping Domon company, had not hesitated to remove his Shienaran topknot to avoid Seanchan notice, though he ran a hand over the black bristle growing on his head about as often as Egeanin checked her wig. Maybe he should wear a cap. In their dark coats with frayed cuffs and well-traveled boots, both men could pass for showfolk, maybe horse-handlers, except to other showfolk. They were watching the Seanchan while trying to seem not to, but Blaeric was the more successful, as might be expected from a Warder. His full attention appeared to be on Domon, except for an occasional glance at the soldiers, as casual as could be. Domon scowled at the Seanchan when he was not glaring at the lump of wood in his hand, as though ordering it to turn into a neat carving. The man had taken being so'jbin entirely too much to heart.

mæt wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə snik kloʊs tə lukəz wæɡən ən ivzdʒɹɑp ənsin baɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz wən ðə dɔɹ ət ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən oʊpən ən ə peɪl-hɛɹd sintʃæn mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə stɛps, plæntɪŋ ə hɛlmət wɪð ə θɪn blu plum ɑn ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪz but tʌtʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd. lukə əpɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɹisplɛndən ɪn skɑɹləɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝsts, boʊɪŋ wɪð ɪlæbɹət flɝɪʃəz əz i fɑloʊd ði ɔfəsɝ. lukə oʊn ət lis tu dʌzən koʊts, moʊst ɹɛɾ ən itʃ ɡɔɾiɝ ðən ðə læst. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ɪz wæɡən wɑz ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɪn ðə ʃoʊ, əɹ i wəd nɑɾ əv hæd ɹum fəɹ əm ɔl.

Mat was trying to figure out how to sneak close to Luca's wagon and eavesdrop unseen by the soldiers when the door at the back of the wagon opened and a pale-haired Seanchan marched down the steps, planting a helmet with a thin blue plume on his head as his boot touched the ground. Luca appeared behind him, resplendent in scarlet embroidered with golden sunbursts, bowing with elaborate flourishes as he followed the officer. Luca owned at least two dozen coats, most red and each gaudier than the last. It was a good thing his wagon was the largest in the show, or he would not have had room for them all.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ lukə, ðə sintʃæn ɔfəsɝ stɛpt ʌp ɑntu hɪz ɡɛldɪŋ, ədʒʌstəɾ ɪz sɔɹd, ən bɑɹkt ɔɹɾɝz ðət sɛn ɪz mɛn floʊɪŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən fɔɹmɪŋ ə kɑləm ə tuz ðət muvd ɔf əɾ ə sloʊ wɔk təwɔɹd ði ɛntʃɹəns. lukə stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ əm liv wɪð ə fɪkst smaɪl ɑn ɪz feɪs, pɔɪz fəɹ ənʌðɝ baʊ ɪf ɛni lʊk bæk.

Ignoring Luca, the Seanchan officer stepped up onto his gelding, adjusted his sword, and barked orders that sent his men flowing into their saddles and forming a column of twos that moved off at a slow walk toward the entrance. Luca stood watching them leave with a fixed smile on his face, poised for another bow if any looked back.

mæt steɪd wɛl tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹiɾ ən lɛɾ ɪz maʊθ hæŋ oʊpən, əfɛktɪŋ tə ɡeɪp ɪn wʌndɝ əz ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹoʊd baɪ. nɑt ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əm soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ɪz weɪ - ði ɔfəsɝ stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ən soʊ dɪd ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪhaɪn ɪm - bʌt noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ peɪɾ ɛni maɪn tə ə kʌntʃɹi joʊkəl, əɹ ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌn. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ɛdʒiənɪn stʌɾid ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ toʊz, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə skɑɹf nɑɾɪd bɪniθ əɹ tʃɪn, əntɪl ðə læs hɔɹsmən pæst. lɪftɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə lʊk æftɝ ðɛm, ʃi pɝst əɹ lɪps fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ɪt simz aɪ də noʊ ðət bɔɪ," ʃi dʒɹɔl sɔfli. "aɪ kæɹiɾ ɪm tə pɑm ɑn fɪɹləs. hɪz sɝvən daɪd, mɪdvɔɪədʒ, ən i θɔɾ i kəd juz wʌn ə maɪ kɹu. aɪ hæd tə pʊɾ ɪm stʃɹeɪt. juɾ əv ðoʊ hi wɑz ə ðə blʌd, ðə fʌs i pʊɾ ʌp."

Mat stayed well to the side of the street and let his mouth hang open, affecting to gape in wonder as the soldiers rode by. Not that any of them so much as glanced his way - the officer stared straight ahead and so did the soldiers behind him - but no one ever paid any mind to a country yokel, or remembered one. To his surprise, Egeanin studied the ground in front of her toes, clutching the scarf knotted beneath her chin, until the last horseman passed. Lifting her head to look after them, she pursed her lips for a moment. "It seems I do know that boy," she drawled softly. "I carried him to Palme on Fearless. His servant died, midvoyage, and he thought he could use one of my crew. I had to put him straight. You'd have though he was of the Blood, the fuss he put up."

"blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz," mæt bɹiðd. haʊ mɛni ʌðɝ pipəl hæd ʃi ɡɑɾən kɹɔswaɪz, fɪksɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɪn ðɛɹ maɪnz? ɛdʒiənɪn biɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪn, pɹɑbli hʌnʒɹədz. ən i hæd bɪn lɛɾɪŋ əɹ wɔk ɝaʊnd wɪð dʒʌst ə wɪɡ ən ə tʃeɪnʒ ə kloʊðz fəɹ dɪsɡaɪz! hʌnʒɹədz? θaʊzənz, mɔɹ laɪkli.

"Blood and bloody ashes," Mat breathed. How many other people had she gotten crosswise, fixing her face in their minds? Egeanin being Egeanin, probably hundreds. And he had been letting her walk around with just a wig and a change of clothes for disguise! Hundreds? Thousands, more likely.

ʃi kəɾ ɪɹɪteɪɾ ə bɹɪk.

She could irritate a brick.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, ði ɔfəsɝ wɑz ɡɔn naʊ. mæt ɛksheɪl sloʊli. hɪz lʌk ɹɪli wɑz stɪl wɪð hɪm. ət taɪmz i θɔt ðət wɑz ɔl ðət kɛpt ɪm fɹəm bɔlɪŋ laɪk ə beɪbi. hi hɛɾəd fəɹ lukə tə faɪn aʊt wʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd wɑntəd.

In any case, the officer was gone now. Mat exhaled slowly. His luck really was still with him. At times he thought that was all that kept him from bawling like a baby. He headed for Luca to find out what the soldiers had wanted.

doʊmən ən blɹɪk ɹitʃt lukə əz kwɪkli əz i ən ɛdʒiənɪn dɪd, ən ðə skaʊl ɑn doʊmənz ɹaʊn feɪs dipən əz i stɛɹɾ ət mæts ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɛdʒiənɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. ði ɪliɑnɝ ʌndɝstʊd ðə nəsɛsəɾi fəɹ ðə pɹitɛns, əɹ sɛɾ i dɪd, jɛɾ i sim tə bɪliv ðeɪ kəd kæɹi ɪɾ ɔf wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʌtʃɪŋ hænz. mæt ɹimuvd ɪz ɑɹm fɹəm əɹ - ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə kæɹi ɔf hɪɹ; lukə nu ðə tʃɹuθ; ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ - ən ɛdʒiənɪn stɑɹɾəd tə ɹilis hɪm, tu, jɛɾ æftɝ ə lʊk ət doʊmən, ʃi taɪɾənd əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn mæts weɪst ɪnstɛd, ɔl wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst tʃeɪnʒ ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən. doʊmən kəntɪnjud tə skaʊl, bʌɾ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd, naʊ. mæt dɪsaɪɾɪd i wəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə sintʃæn lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i ʌndɝstʊd wɪmən. əɹ ɪliɑnɝz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Domon and Blaeric reached Luca as quickly as he and Egeanin did, and the scowl on Domon's round face deepened as he stared at Mat's arm around Egeanin's shoulder. The Illianer understood the necessity for the pretense, or said he did, yet he seemed to believe they could carry it off without so much as touching hands. Mat removed his arm from her - there was nothing to carry off here; Luca knew the truth; of everything - and Egeanin started to release him, too, yet after a look at Domon, she tightened her grip on Mat's waist instead, all without the slightest change of expression. Domon continued to scowl, but at the ground, now. Mat decided he would understand the Seanchan long before he understood women. Or Illianers, for that matter.

"hɔɹsəz," lukə ɡɹaʊld ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ mæt stɑpt wɔkɪŋ. hɪz fɹaʊn tʊk ɪn ɔl ə ðɛm, bʌɾ i foʊkəs moʊst ə hɪz æŋɡɝ ɑn mæt. ə lɪɾəl ðə tɔlɝ, lukə stʃɹɛtʃt tə stɛɹ daʊn ət mæt. "ðæts wʌɾ i wɑntəd. aɪ ʃoʊɾ ɪm ðə wɔɹən ɪɡzɛmptɪŋ mi fɹəm ðə hɔɹs lɑɾɝi, saɪn baɪ ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ hɝsɛlf, bʌt wɑz i ɪmpɹɛst? ɪt dɪdn mæɾɝ tə hɪm ðəɾ aɪ ɹɛskjuɾ ə haɪɹæŋkɪŋ sintʃæn." ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt bɪn haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ, ən i hæd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ ɹɛskjuɾ əɹ əz ɡɪvən əɹ ə weɪ tə tʃɹævəl əz ə haɪɝd pɝfɔɹmɝ, bʌt lukə ɔlweɪz ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd tə hɪz oʊn ædvæntɪdʒ. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ ɪɡzɛmpʃən ɪz ɹɪli ɡʊd fɔɹ, ɛniweɪ. ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ dɛspɹɪt fəɹ hɔɹsəz. ðeɪ maɪt teɪk ɪt bæk ɛni deɪ!" hɪz feɪs wɑz tɝnɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ɹɛɾ əz ɪz koʊt, ən i dʒæbd ə fɪŋɡɝ ət mæt ɹɪpiɾɪdli. "jɔɹ gɑnə ɡɛt maɪ hɔɹsəz teɪkən! haʊ də aɪ muv maɪ ʃoʊ wɪð noʊ hɔɹsəz? ænsɝ mi ðæt, ɪf jə kæn. aɪ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə liv əz sun əz aɪ sɔ ðət mædnəs ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ, əntɪl jə twɪstəd maɪ ɑɹm. jəɹ gɑnə ɡɛt maɪ hɛd kʌɾ ɔf! aɪ kəd bi ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz fɹəm hɪɹ, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ju, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn aʊɾ ə ðə naɪɾ ən snɛɹɪŋ mi ɪn jəɹ kɹeɪzi skimz! aɪm nɑɾ ɝnɪŋ ə pɛni hɪɹ! ðəɹ hævən bɪn ɪnʌf peɪtʃɹənz ðə læs θɹi deɪz tə peɪ fəɹ fiɾɪŋ ði ænəməlz wʌn deɪ! hæf ə deɪ! aɪ ʃʊɾə lɛft ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ! mɔɹ! aɪ ʃəd hæv!" mæt ɔlmoʊs læft əz lukə ɹæn daʊn ɪndə spləɾɝz.

"Horses," Luca growled almost before Mat stopped walking. His frown took in all of them, but he focused most of his anger on Mat. A little the taller, Luca stretched to stare down at Mat. "That's what he wanted. I showed him the warrant exempting me from the horse lottery, signed by the High Lady Suroth herself, but was he impressed? It didn't matter to him that I rescued a highranking Seanchan." The woman had not been high-ranking, and he had not so much rescued her as given her a way to travel as a hired performer, but Luca always exaggerated to his own advantage. "I don't know how long that exemption is really good for, anyway. The Seanchan are desperate for horses. They might take it back any day!" His face was turning almost as red as his coat, and he jabbed a finger at Mat repeatedly. "You're going to get my horses taken! How do I move my show with no horses? Answer me that, if you can. I was ready to leave as soon as I saw that madness in the harbor, until you twisted my arm. You're going to get my head cut off! I could be a hundred miles from here, if not for you, riding in out of the night and snaring me in your crazy schemes! I'm not earning a penny here! There haven't been enough patrons the last three days to pay for feeding the animals one day! Half a day! I should have left a month ago! More! I should have!" Mat almost laughed as Luca ran down into splutters.

hɔɹsəz. ðət wɑz ɔl; dʒʌs hɔɹsəz. bɪsaɪdz, ðə noʊʃən ðət ðə ʃoʊz hɛvɪləɾən wæɡənz kəd kʌvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɪn faɪv deɪz wɑz əz luɾəkɹəs əz lukəz wæɡən. ðə mæn cʊɾə ɡɔn ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ, tu mʌnθs, ɪksɛp fəɹ wɑntɪŋ tə ik ɛvɹi kɑpɝ i kəɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ ən ɪts sintʃæn kɑŋkɝɝz. ən əz fəɹ tɔkɪŋ ɪm ɪndə steɪɪŋ, sɪks naɪts pæst, ðət hæd bɪn əz izi əz fɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ə bɛd. ɪnstɛɾ ə læfɪŋ, mæt pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn lukəz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə fɛloʊ wɑz veɪn əz ə pikɑk, ən ɡɹiɾi bɪsaɪdz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn meɪkɪŋ ɪm æŋɡɹiɝ ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz. "ɪf jud lɛf ðət naɪt, lukə, jə θɪŋk noʊbɑdi wʊɾə ɡɑɾən səspɪʃəs? jə wʊɾə hæd sintʃæn tɛɹɪŋ jəɹ wæɡənz əpɑɹt bɪfɔɹ jə meɪd tu liɡz. jə kəd seɪ aɪ seɪv jə fɹəm ðæt." lukə ɡlaʊɝd.

Horses. That was all; just horses. Besides, the notion that the show's heavyladen wagons could cover a hundred miles in five days was as ludicrous as Luca's wagon. The man could have gone a month ago, two months, except for wanting to eke every copper he could out of Ebou Dar and its Seanchan conquerors. And as for talking him into staying, six nights past, that had been as easy as falling out of bed. Instead of laughing, Mat put a hand on Luca's shoulder. The fellow was vain as a peacock, and greedy besides, but there was no point making him angrier than he already was. "If you'd left that night, Luca, you think nobody would have gotten suspicious? You would have had Seanchan tearing your wagons apart before you made two leagues. You could say I saved you from that." Luca glowered.

səm pipəl dʒʌs kəd nɑt si bɪɑn ðɛɹ oʊn noʊzɪz. "ɛniweɪ, jə kən stɑp wɝiɪŋ. əz sun əz tɑm ɹɪtɝnz fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, wi kən pʊɾ əz mɛni maɪlz bɪhaɪn əs əz jə wɑnt." lukə lɛp soʊ sʌɾənli ðət mæt stɛp bæk ɪn əlɑɹm, bʌɾ ɔl ðə mæn dɪd wɑz keɪpɝ ɪn ə lɪɾəl sɝkəl læfɪŋ. doʊmən ɡɑɡəld ət hɪm, ən ivən blɹɪk stɛɹd. səmtaɪmz, lukə simd ə flæt bʊl-ɡus ful.

Some people just could not see beyond their own noses. "Anyway, you can stop worrying. As soon as Thom returns from the city, we can put as many miles behind us as you want." Luca leaped so suddenly that Mat stepped back in alarm, but all the man did was caper in a little circle laughing. Domon goggled at him, and even Blaeric stared. Sometimes, Luca seemed a flat bull-goose fool.

lukə hæd bɛɹli bɪɡʌn ɪz dæns wən ɛdʒiənɪn ʃʌv mæt əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. "æz sun əz mɛɹɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnz? aɪ ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz noʊ wʌn wɑz tə liv!" hɝ ɡlɛɹ swʌŋ bɪtwin ɪm ən lukə ɪn koʊl fjʊɹi, ə koʊl ðət bɝnd. "aɪ ɪkspɛk maɪ ɔɹɾɝz tə bi oʊbeɪd!" lukə stɑp kəvɔɹɾɪŋ əbɹʌpli ən aɪɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, ðən sʌɾənli meɪɾ əɹ ə baʊ wɪð soʊ mɛni flɝɪʃəz jə kəd pɹæktəkli si ðə kloʊk. jə kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ðə kloʊk! hi θɔɾ i hæɾ ə weɪ wɪð ə wɪmən, lukə dɪd. "ju kəmænd, maɪ swit leɪɾi, ən aɪ lip tə oʊbeɪ." kʌmɪŋ əpɹaɪt, hi ʃɹʌɡd əpɑlədʒɛɾɪkli. "bʌt mæstɝ kɔθən əz ɡoʊld, ən aɪ fɪɹ ɡoʊl kəmænz maɪ fɝst oʊbiɾiəns." mæts tʃɛs fʊl ʌv ɡoʊl kɔɪnz ɪn ðɪs vɛɹi wæɡən hæd bɪn ɔl ði ɑɹm-twɪstɪŋ niɾəd tə kənvɪns hɪm. meɪbi mæt biɪŋ tɑvɝən hæd hɛlpt, bʌt fəɹ ɪnʌf ɡoʊld, vɑlən lukə wəd hɛlp kɪdnæp ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹɛɾi tə bɪɹeɪt lukə fɝðɝ, bʌt ðə mæn tɝn ɪz bæk ən wɛn skæmpɝɪŋ ʌp ðə stɛps ɪndə hɪz wæɡən ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "lətɛl! lətɛl! wi mʌst ɹst ɛvɹibɑɾi aʊɾ ɪmiɾiətli! wɝ livɪŋ ət læst, ðə mɪnət mɛɹɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnz! ðə laɪt bi pɹeɪzd!"

Luca had barely begun his dance when Egeanin shoved Mat away from her. "As soon as Merrilin returns? I gave orders no one was to leave!" Her glare swung between him and Luca in cold fury, a cold that burned. "I expect my orders to be obeyed!" Luca stopped cavorting abruptly and eyed her sideways, then suddenly made her a bow with so many flourishes you could practically see the cloak. You could almost see the embroidery on the cloak! He thought he had a way with a women, Luca did. "You command, my sweet Lady, and I leap to obey." Coming upright, he shrugged apologetically. "But Master Cauthon has gold, and I fear gold commands my first obedience." Mat's chest full of gold coins in this very wagon had been all the arm-twisting needed to convince him. Maybe Mat being ta'veren had helped, but for enough gold, Valan Luca would help kidnap the Dark One. Egeanin drew a deep breath, ready to berate Luca further, but the man turned his back and went scampering up the steps into his wagon shouting, "Latelle! Latelle! We must roust everybody out immediately! We're leaving at last, the minute Merrilin returns! The Light be praised!"

ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, hi wɑz bæk əɡɛn, dæʃɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə ʃɔɹt stɛɹ fɑloʊd baɪ hɪz waɪf dʒɹɔɪŋ ə blæk vɛlvət kloʊk, soʊn wɪð ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ spæŋɡəlz, ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf. ə stɝn-feɪst wʊmən, ʃi ɹɪŋkəld əɹ noʊz ət mæt əz ðoʊ hi hæɾ ə bæd smɛl ən ɡeɪv ɛdʒiənɪn ə lʊk ðət laɪkli meɪɾ əɹ tʃɹeɪn bɛɹz klaɪm tʃɹiz. lətɛl dɪslaɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv ə wʊmən ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ hʌzbən ivən wən ʃi nu ɪt wɑz ə laɪ. lʌkəli, ʃi sim tə wɝʃəp lukə fəɹ səm ɹizən, ən ʃi laɪkt ɡoʊl nɪɹli əz wɛl əz i dɪd. lukə ɹæn tə ðə nɪɹəst wæɡən ən bɪɡæn paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹ, ən lətɛl dɪd ðə seɪm ət ðə nɛkst.

A moment later, he was back again, dashing back down the short stair followed by his wife drawing a black velvet cloak, sewn with glittering spangles, around herself. A stern-faced woman, she wrinkled her nose at Mat as though he had a bad smell and gave Egeanin a look that likely made her trained bears climb trees. Latelle disliked the idea of a woman running away from her husband even when she knew it was a lie. Luckily, she seemed to worship Luca for some reason, and she liked gold nearly as well as he did. Luca ran to the nearest wagon and began pounding on the door, and Latelle did the same at the next.

nɑt weɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn tə wɑtʃ, mæt hɝiɾ ɔf daʊn wʌn ə ðə saɪd stʃɹits. mɔɹ ʌv ən æli kəmpɛɹd tə ðə meɪn stʃɹit, ɪt waʊn əmʌŋ ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ʌv wæɡənz ən tɛns, ɔl ʃʌɾ ʌp taɪɾ əɡɛns ðə koʊld, wɪð smoʊk stʃɹimɪŋ fɹəm ðə mɛɾəl tʃɪmniz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ plætfɔɹmz fəɹ pɝfɔɹmɝz hɪɹ, bʌt laɪnz fəɹ dʒɹaɪɪŋ lɔnʒɹi hʌŋ bɪtwin səm ə ðə wæɡənz, ən hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wʊɾən tɔɪz leɪ skæɾɝd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðɪs stʃɹit wɑz fəɹ lɪvɪŋ oʊnli, ðə nɛɹoʊnəs mɛn tə dɪskɝɪdʒ aʊtsaɪɾɝz.

Not waiting around to watch, Mat hurried off down one of the side streets. More of an alley compared to the main street, it wound among the same sort of wagons and tents, all shut up tight against the cold, with smoke streaming from the metal chimneys. There were no platforms for performers here, but lines for drying laundry hung between some of the wagons, and here and there wooden toys lay scattered on the ground. This street was for living only, the narrowness meant to discourage outsiders.

hi muv kwɪkli dɪspaɪɾ ɪz hɪp - hi hæd wɔk moʊst ə ði eɪk aʊt - bʌɾ i hæd nɑt ɡɔn tɛn stɛps bɪfɔɹ ɛdʒiənɪn ən doʊmən kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm. blɹɪk hæd vænɪʃt, pɹɑbli ɡɔn tə tɛl ðə sɪstɝz ðeɪ wɝ stɪl seɪf ən kəd faɪnəli liv. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, mæskɝeɪɾɪŋ əz sɝvəns sɪk wɪð wɝi ðət ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz hʌzbənd wəd kætʃ ðɛm, wɝ fɛɾ ʌp wɪð biɪŋ kənfaɪn tə ðɛɹ wæɡən, nɑt tə mɛnʃən fɛɾ ʌp wɪð ʃɛɹɪŋ wɪð ðə sʌl'-dæm. mæt hæd meɪɾ əm ʃɛɹ, soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd wɑtʃ ðə mldəm waɪl ðə sʌldəm kɛp ði ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɹ. stɪl mæt wɑz ɡlæd blɹɪk hæd teɪkən əweɪ ðə nəsɛsəɾi fəɹ ɪm tə vɪzət ðət wæɡən əɡɛn. wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ə ðə sɪstɝz hæd sʌmən ɪm fɔɹ əɹ faɪv taɪmz ə deɪ sɪns ðɛɹ ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ən i wɛnt wən i kəd nɑɾ əvɔɪɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ ə plɛzən ɪkspɪɹiəns. ɛdʒiənɪn dɪd nɑt pʊɾ əɹ ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɪm ðɪs taɪm. ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə tʃɛk əɹ wɪɡ, fəɹ wʌns. doʊmən lʌmbɝd bɪhaɪn laɪk ə bɛɹ, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ ɪn ɪz hɛvi ɪliɑnɝ æksɛnt. ðə stɑkɪŋ kæp ɪkspoʊz ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪz dɑɹk bɪɹd stɑpt əbɹʌpli ət ðə mɪɾəl ʌv itʃ ɪɹ, wɪð oʊnli stʌbəl əbʌv. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm lʊk . . .

He moved quickly despite his hip - he had walked most of the ache out - but he had not gone ten steps before Egeanin and Domon caught up to him. Blaeric had vanished, probably gone to tell the sisters they were still safe and could finally leave. The Aes Sedai, masquerading as servants sick with worry that their mistress's husband would catch them, were fed up with being confined to their wagon, not to mention fed up with sharing with the sul'-dam. Mat had made them share, so the Aes Sedai could watch the ml'dam while the sul'dam kept the Aes Sedai out of his hair. Still Mat was glad Blaeric had taken away the necessity for him to visit that wagon again. One or another of the sisters had summoned him four or five times a day since their escape from the city, and he went when he could not avoid it, but it was never a pleasant experience. Egeanin did not put her arm around him this time. She strode at his side staring straight ahead, not bothering to check her wig, for once. Domon lumbered behind like a bear, muttering under his breath in his heavy Illianer accent. The stocking cap exposed the fact that his dark beard stopped abruptly at the middle of each ear, with only stubble above. It made him look . . .

ənfɪnɪʃt. "tu kæptənz ɑn wʌn ʃɪp meɪk ʃʊɹ kɔɹs fəɹ dɪzæstɝ," ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɹɔld wɪð oʊvɝdʌn peɪʃəns. hɝ ʌndɝstændɪŋ smaɪl lʊkt əz ɪf ɪt hɝɾ əɹ feɪs.

unfinished. "Two captains on one ship make sure course for disaster," Egeanin drawled with overdone patience. Her understanding smile looked as if it hurt her face.

"wi ɑɹən ɑn ə ʃɪp," mæt ɹɪplaɪd.

"We aren't on a ship," Mat replied.

"ðə pɹɪnsəpəlz ðə seɪm, kɔθən! jə ɑɹ ə fɑɹmɝ. aɪ noʊ jəɹ ə ɡʊd mæn ɪn ə taɪt spɑt." ɛdʒiənɪn ʃɑɾ ə dɑɹk lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət doʊmən. hi wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd bɹɔɾ əɹ ən mæt təɡɛðɝ, bæk wən ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ə haɪɝd mæn. "bʌt ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən nidz dʒʌdʒmən ən ɪkspɪɹiəns. wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝəs wɔɾɝz, ən juv noʊ nɑlədʒ ə kəmænd."

"The principle's the same, Cauthon! You are a farmer. I know you're a good man in a tight spot." Egeanin shot a dark look over her shoulder at Domon. He was the one who had brought her and Mat together, back when she thought she was getting a hired man. "But this situation needs judgment and experience. We're in dangerous waters, and you have no knowledge of command."

"mɔɹ ðən jə maɪt θɪŋk," hi toʊld əɹ dʒɹaɪli. hi cʊɾə spʌn aʊɾ ə lɪst ə ðə bæɾəlz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd kəmændɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli ən hɪstɔɹiən wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz moʊst ə ðɛm, ən meɪbi nɑɾ ivən ən hɪstɔɹiən. noʊ wʌn wəd bɪliv ɪt, ɛniweɪ. hi sɝɾənli wəd nɑɾ ɪf sʌmwʌn ɛls hæd meɪd ðət kleɪm. "ʃʊdn jə ən doʊmən bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi? jə wʊdnt wɑnə liv ɛniθɪŋ bɪhaɪnd." ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi oʊnd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi stoʊɾ əweɪ ɪn ðə wæɡən ʃi ən mæt ʃɛɹd wɪð doʊmən - nɑɾ ə kʌmftəɹbəl ɝeɪnʒmənt, ðət - bʌɾ i kwɪkən ɪz stɛp, hoʊpɪŋ ʃi wəd teɪk ðə hɪnt. bɪsaɪdz, hi sɔ hɪz dɛstəneɪʃən əhɛd. ðə bɹaɪt blu wɔl-tɛnt, kɹaʊɾəd bɪtwin ə vɪɹələn jɛloʊ wæɡən ən ən ɛmɹəld ɡɹin wʌn, wɑz bɛɹli lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə hoʊl θɹi kɑts, bʌt pɹəvaɪɾɪŋ ʃɛltɝ fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn i bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ hæd ɹikwaɪɝd bɹaɪbz tə meɪk pipəl muv ən mɔɹ bɹaɪbz tə meɪk ʌðɝz lɛɾ əm ɪn. wʌɾ i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə haɪɝ wɑz wʌt ði oʊnɝz wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə lɛɾ ɪm hæv. ət ɹeɪts suɾəbəl fəɹ ə ɡʊɾ ɪn. dʒulɪn, ə dɑɹk kɑmpæk mæn wɪð ʃɔɹt blæk hɛɹ, wɑz sɪɾɪŋ kɹɑslɛɡd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛnt wɪð oʊlvɝ, ə θɪn lɪɾəl bɔɪ, ɪf nɑt soʊ skɪni əz wən mæt fɝst sɔ hɪm, ən ʃɔɹt fəɹ tɛn, ði eɪdʒ i kleɪmd. boʊθ koʊtləs dɪspaɪt ðə wɪnd, ðeɪ wɝ pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz ɑn ə bɔɹd ðə bɔɪz dɛd fɑðɝ hæd dʒɹɔn fəɹ ɪm ɑn ə pis ə ɹɛd klɔθ.

"More than you might think," he told her dryly. He could have spun out a list of the battles he remembered commanding, but only an historian would recognize most of them, and maybe not even an historian. No one would believe it, anyway. He certainly would not if someone else had made that claim. "Shouldn't you and Domon be getting ready? You wouldn't want to leave anything behind." Everything she owned was already stowed away in the wagon she and Mat shared with Domon - not a comfortable arrangement, that - but he quickened his step, hoping she would take the hint. Besides, he saw his destination ahead. The bright blue wall-tent, crowded between a virulent yellow wagon and an emerald green one, was barely large enough to hold three cots, but providing shelter for everyone he brought out of Ebou Dar had required bribes to make people move and more bribes to make others let them in. What he had been able to hire was what the owners were willing to let him have. At rates suitable for a good inn. Juilin, a dark compact man with short black hair, was sitting crosslegged on the ground in front of the tent with Olver, a thin little boy, if not so skinny as when Mat first saw him, and short for ten, the age he claimed. Both coatless despite the wind, they were playing Snakes and Foxes on a board the boy's dead father had drawn for him on a piece of red cloth.

tɔsɪŋ ðə daɪs, oʊlvɝ kaʊntəd ðə pɪps kɛɹfəli ən kənsɪɾɝd ɪz muv əlɔŋ ðə spaɪɾɝwɛb ə blæk laɪnz ən æɹoʊz. ðə tɛɹən θif-kætʃɝ wɑz peɪɪŋ lɛs ətɛnʃən tə ðə ɡeɪm. hi sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə mæt.

Tossing the dice, Olver counted the pips carefully and considered his move along the spiderweb of black lines and arrows. The Tairen thief-catcher was paying less attention to the game. He sat up straight at the sight of Mat.

əbɹʌpli, noʊl dɑɹɾɪd ɝaʊn fɹəm ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə tɛnt, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ.

Abruptly, Noal darted around from the rear of the tent, breathing hard as if he had been running.

dʒulɪn ɡlænst ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz ət ði oʊl mæn, ən mæt fɹaʊnd. hi hæd toʊl noʊl tə kʌm stʃɹeɪt hɪɹ.

Juilin glanced up in surprise at the old man, and Mat frowned. He had told Noal to come straight here.

wɛɹ hæɾ i ɡɔn ɪnstɛd? noʊl lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɪkspɛktənli, nɑt wɪð ɛni ɡɪlt əɹ ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, dʒʌst iɡɝ tə hɪɹ wʌt mæt hæd tə seɪ.

Where had he gone instead? Noal looked at him expectantly, not with any guilt or embarrassment, just eager to hear what Mat had to say.

"ju noʊ əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn?" dʒulɪn æskt, tɝnɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən tə mæt, tu.

"You know about the Seanchan?" Juilin asked, turning his attention to Mat, too.

ə ʃædoʊ muvd ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛns ɛntʃɹi flæps, ən ə dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən, siɾəd ɑn ði ɛn ʌv wʌn ə ðə kɑts wɪð ən oʊld ɡɹeɪ kloʊk ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɝ, lin fɔɹwɝd tə ɹɛst ə hæn ɑn dʒulɪnz ɑɹm.

A shadow moved inside the tent's entry flaps, and a dark-haired woman, seated on the end of one of the cots with an old gray cloak wrapped around her, leaned forward to rest a hand on Juilin's arm.

ən tə ɡɪv mæt ə wɛɹi lʊk. θɛɹə wɑz pɹɪɾi, ɪf jə laɪkt ə maʊθ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə bi paʊɾɪŋ, ən ɪt sim ðət dʒulɪn dɪd, fɹəm ðə weɪ hi smaɪld əɾ əɹ ɹiəʃɝɪŋli ən pæɾəd əɹ hænd. ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ æməðɛɹə æɛlfdin kæsmɪɹ laʊnoʊ, pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən ən ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə ə kwin. ət list, ʃi hæd bɪn, wʌns. dʒulɪn hæd noʊn ðæt, ən soʊ hæd tɑm, jɛt noʊ wʌn θɔt tə tɛl mæt əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə ʃoʊ. hi səpoʊzd ɪt hɑɹdli mæɾɝd, əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. ʃi ænsɝd fæstɝ tə θɛɹə ðən tə æməðɛɹə, ʃi meɪd noʊ dɪmænz, ɪksɛpt ɑn dʒulɪnz taɪm, ən ðəɹ sim lɪɾəl tʃæns ɛniwʌn wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ hɪɹ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, mæt hoʊpt ʃi fɛl mɔɹ ðən ɡɹæɾətud fəɹ biɪŋ ɹɛskjud, kəz dʒulɪn sɝɾənli fɛl mɔɹ fəɹ hɝ. hu wɑz tə seɪ ə dɪθɹoʊn pɑnɑɹtʃ kəd nɑt fɔl ɪn lʌv wɪð ə θif-kætʃɝ? stʃɹeɪnʒɝ θɪŋz hæd hæpənd. ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd neɪm wʌn, ɔfhænd. "ðeɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə si ðə wɔɹən fəɹ lukəz hɔɹsəz," hi sɛd, ən dʒulɪn nɑɾəd, vɪzəbli ɹɪlæksɪŋ ə lɪɾəl.

And to give Mat a wary look. Thera was pretty, if you liked a mouth that always seemed to be pouting, and it seemed that Juilin did, from the way he smiled at her reassuringly and patted her hand. She was also Amathera Aelfdene Casmir Lounault, Panarch of Tarabon and the next thing to a queen. At least, she had been, once. Juilin had known that, and so had Thom, yet no one thought to tell Mat until they reached the show. He supposed it hardly mattered, alongside everything else. She answered faster to Thera than to Amathera, she made no demands, except on Juilin's time, and there seemed little chance anyone would recognize her here.
