In any case, Mat hoped she felt more than gratitude for being rescued, because Juilin certainly felt more for her. Who was to say a dethroned panarch could not fall in love with a thief-catcher? Stranger things had happened. Though he was not sure he could name one, offhand. "They just wanted to see the warrant for Luca's horses," he said, and Juilin nodded, visibly relaxing a little.

"æz wɛl ðeɪ dɪdn kaʊn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz." ðə wɔɹən lɪstəd ði ɪɡzæk nʌmbɝ ə hɔɹsəz lukə wɑz əlaʊd tə kip. ðə sintʃæn kəd bi dʒɛnɝəs wɪð ðɛɹ ɹɪwɔɹdz, bʌt ɡɪvən ðɛɹ nid fəɹ maʊns ən wæɡən timz, ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əbaʊt tə hæn ɛniwʌn ə laɪsəns tə sɛɾ ʌp hɔɹs tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ. "æt bɛst, ðeɪ wʊɾə teɪkən ði ɛkstʃɹə. ət wɝst. . . ." ðə θif-kætʃɝ ʃɹʌɡd. ənʌðɝ tʃɪɹfəl soʊl.

"As well they didn't count the horselines." The warrant listed the exact number of horses Luca was allowed to keep. The Seanchan could be generous with their rewards, but given their need for mounts and wagon teams, they were not about to hand anyone a license to set up horse trading. "At best, they would have taken the extra. At worst. . . ." The thief-catcher shrugged. Another cheerful soul.

wɪð ə ɡæsp, θɛɹə sʌɾənli pʊld əɹ kloʊk taɪɾɝ ən dʒɝk bæk ɪndə ðə dɛpθs ə ðə tɛnt.

With a gasp, Thera suddenly pulled her cloak tighter and jerked back into the depths of the tent.

dʒulɪn lʊk bɪhaɪn mæt, hɪz aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ hɑɹd, ən ðə tɛɹən kəd mætʃ ðə wɔɹɾɝz wən ɪt keɪm tə hɑɹd. ɛdʒiənɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə kætʃ hɪns, ən ʃi wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tɛnt. doʊmən stʊd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəd, sʌkɪŋ ɪz tiθ ɪn θɔɾ əɹ fɔɹs peɪʃəns. "ɡɛt jəɹ tɛn pækt ʌp, sændɑɹ," ɛdʒiənɪn ɔɹɾɝd. "ðə ʃoʊ ɪz livɪŋ əz sun əz mɛɹɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnz." hɝ dʒɔ taɪɾənd, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt kwaɪt ɡlɛɹ ət mæt. nɑt kwaɪt. "meɪk ʃʊɹ jəɹ . . . wʊmən . . . dʌznt ɡɪv ɛni tʃɹʌbəl." moʊs leɪtli, θɛɹə hæd bɪn ə sɝvənt, dækoʊvæl, ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ, əntɪl dʒulɪn stoʊl əɹ əweɪ.

Juilin looked behind Mat, his eyes going hard, and the Tairen could match the Warders when it came to hard. Egeanin did not seem to catch hints, and she was glaring at the tent. Domon stood beside her with his arms folded, sucking his teeth in thought or forced patience. "Get your tent packed up, Sandar," Egeanin ordered. "The show is leaving as soon as Merrilin returns." Her jaw tightened, and she did not quite glare at Mat. Not quite. "Make sure your . . . woman . . . doesn't give any trouble." Most lately, Thera had been a servant, da'covale, the property of the High Lady Suroth, until Juilin stole her away.

tə ɛdʒiənɪn, stilɪŋ dækoʊvæl wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz fɹiɪŋ deɪmeɪn.

To Egeanin, stealing da'covale was almost as bad as freeing damane.

"kæn aɪ ɹaɪd wɪnd?" oʊlvɝ ɪkskleɪmd, baʊndɪŋ tə hɪz fit. "kæn aɪ, mæt? kən aɪ, laɪlwɪn?" ɛdʒiənɪn æktʃəli  smaɪld ət hɪm. mæt hæd jɛt tə si hɝ smaɪl əɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls, ivən doʊmən. "nɑt jɛt," mæt sɛd. nɑɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ ɪnʌf fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ ðət noʊ wʌn wɑz laɪkli tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ɡɹeɪ wɪnɪŋ ɹeɪsəz wɪð ə smɔl bɔɪ ɑn ɪz bæk. "ɪn ə fju deɪz, meɪbi. dʒulɪn, wɪl jə tɛl ði ʌðɝz?

"Can I ride Wind?" Olver exclaimed, bounding to his feet. "Can I, Mat? Can I, Leilwin?" Egeanin actually smiled at him. Mat had yet to see her smile at anyone else, even Domon. "Not yet," Mat said. Not until they were far enough from Ebou Dar that no one was likely to remember the gray winning races with a small boy on his back. "In a few days, maybe. Juilin, will you tell the others?

blɹɪk ɔlɹɛɾi noʊz, soʊ ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹ teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv." dʒulɪn dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm, əsaɪd fɹəm dʌkɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə tɛn tə ɹiəʃʊɹ θɛɹə. ʃi sim tə nid ɹiəʃʊɹɪŋ fɹikwənli. wən i keɪm aʊt, kæɹiɪŋ ə dɑɹk tɛɹən koʊt ðət wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ wɛɹ, hi toʊld oʊlvɝ tə pʊt ðə ɡeɪm əweɪ ən hɛlp θɛɹə wɪð ðə pækɪŋ əntɪl i ɹɪtɝnd, ðən sɛɾəld ɪz flæt-tɑp kɑnɪkəl ɹɛd hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛɾ ən stɑɹɾəd ɔf, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪndə ðə koʊt. hi nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst əɾ ɛdʒiənɪn. ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ɪm ə θif, əfɛnsɪv ɪn ɪtsɛlf tə ə θif-kætʃɝ, ən ðə tɛɹən hæd noʊ lʌv fəɹ hɝ, iðɝ. mæt stɑɹɾəd tə æsk noʊl wɛɹ i hæd bɪn, bʌt ði oʊl mæn dɑɹɾɪd nɪmbli æftɝ dʒulɪn, kɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ðəɾ i wəd hɛlp lɛt ði ʌðɝz noʊ ðə ʃoʊ wɑz livɪŋ. wɛl, tu kəd spɹɛd ðə wɝd fæstɝ ðən wʌn - veɪnɪn ən ðə fɔɹ sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɹɛdʒɹmz ʃɛɹɾ ə kɹaʊɾəd tɛn ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə ʃoʊ, waɪl noʊl hɪmsɛlf ʃɛɹɾ ənʌðɝ wɪð tɑm ən ðə tu sɝvɪŋ mɛn, ləpɪn ən nɹɪm, ɑn ði ɑpəzət saɪd - ən ðə kwɛstʃən kəd weɪt. pɹɑbli, hi hæd dʒʌs dɪleɪd tə pʊɾ ɪz pɹɛʃəs fɪʃ sʌmwɛɹ seɪf. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə kwɛstʃən sʌɾənli simd ənɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə nɔɪz ə pipəl ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ hɔɹs hænlɝz tə bɹɪŋ ðɛɹ timz, ən ʌðɝz dɪmændɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz tə noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɪl ðə kæmp.

Blaeric already knows, so the sisters are taken care of." Juilin did not waste time, aside from ducking inside the tent to reassure Thera. She seemed to need reassuring frequently. When he came out, carrying a dark Tairen coat that was beginning to show wear, he told Olver to put the game away and help Thera with the packing until he returned, then settled his flat-topped conical red hat on his head and started off, shrugging into the coat. He never so much as glanced at Egeanin. She considered him a thief, offensive in itself to a thief-catcher, and the Tairen had no love for her, either. Mat started to ask Noal where he had been, but the old man darted nimbly after Juilin, calling over his shoulder that he would help let the others know the show was leaving. Well, two could spread the word faster than one - Vanin and the four surviving Redarms shared a crowded tent on one side of the show, while Noal himself shared another with Thom and the two serving men, Lopin and Nerim, on the opposite side - and the question could wait. Probably, he had just delayed to put his precious fish somewhere safe. In any case, the question suddenly seemed unimportant. The noise of people shouting for horse handlers to bring their teams, and others demanding at the top of their lungs to know what was happening, was beginning to fill the camp.

ɑdʒɹiə, ə slɪm wʊmən hoʊldɪŋ ə flaʊɝd ɡɹin ɹoʊb ɝaʊn hɝ, keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ɪn bɛɹ fiɾ ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə jɛloʊ wæɡən, wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ kəntɔɹʃənɪsts lɪvd. sʌmbɑɾi ɪn ðə ɡɹin wæɡən bɛloʊd hɔɹsli ðət pipəl wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə slip. ə hændfʊl ə pɝfɔɹmɝz' tʃɪlʒɹən, səm pɝfɔɹmɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, dæʃt baɪ, ən oʊlvɝ lʊkt ʌp fɹəm foʊldɪŋ ðə ɡeɪm. ðət wɑz ɪz moʊs pɹaɪz pəzɛʃən, bʌɾ ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðæt, hi pleɪnli wʊɾə ɡɔn æftɝ ðɛm. ɪt wɑz gɑnə teɪk səm taɪm jɛt bɪfɔɹ ðə ʃoʊ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə tʃɹævəl, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt meɪd mæt ɡɹoʊn. hi hæd dʒʌs hɝd ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs stɑɹt ɹætlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn.

Adria, a slim woman holding a flowered green robe around her, came running up in bare feet and vanished into the yellow wagon, where the other four contortionists lived. Somebody in the green wagon bellowed hoarsely that people were trying to sleep. A handful of performers' children, some performers themselves, dashed by, and Olver looked up from folding the game. That was his most prized possession, but if not for that, he plainly would have gone after them. It was going to take some time yet before the show was ready to travel, but that was not what made Mat groan. He had just heard those bloody dice start rattling in his head again.

tʃæptɝ θɹi

CHAPTER 3

eɪ fæn ə kʌlɝz ət dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə kɝs əɹ wip. wɪð ðə soʊlʒɝz ɡɔn ən ɛbu dɑɹ əbaʊt tə bi lɛft ɪn ɪz dʌst, ðəɹ sim noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ðə daɪs, bʌt ðəɹ nɛvɝ wɑz ə blʌɾi ɹizən i kəd si əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz kʌmɪŋ maɪt laɪ deɪz ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ əɹ oʊnli ən aʊɝ, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə fɪɡjɝ ɪɾ aʊɾ əhɛɾ ə taɪm. ði oʊnli sɝɾəntiz wɝ ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt - əɹ daɪɹ - wɑz gɑnə hæpən ən ðəɾ i wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt. səmtaɪmz, laɪk ðət naɪɾ ət ðə ɡeɪt, hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðə daɪs hæd bɪn tʌmbəlɪŋ ivən æftɝ ðeɪ stɑpt. ɔl i ɹɪli nu fəɹ ʃʊɹ wɑz ðət haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðə daɪs meɪɾ ɪm twɪtʃ laɪk ə ɡoʊt wɪð ði ɪtʃ, wʌns ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd, hi dɪd nɑt wɑn əm tə stɑp ɛvɝ. bʌt ðeɪ dɪd. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðeɪ ɔlweɪz dɪd.

A Fan of Colors at did not know whether to curse or weep. With the soldiers gone and Ebou Dar about to be left in his dust, there seemed no reason for the dice, but there never was a bloody reason he could see until it was too late. Whatever was coming might lie days in the future or only an hour, but he had never been able to figure it out ahead of time. The only certainties were that something important - or dire - was going to happen and that he would not be able to avoid it. Sometimes, like that night at the gate, he did not understand why the dice had been tumbling even after they stopped. All he really knew for sure was that however much the dice made him twitch like a goat with the itch, once they started, he did not want them to stop ever. But they did. Sooner or later, they always did.

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt?" oʊlvɝ sɛd. "ðoʊz sintʃæn kæn kætʃ ʌs." hi ətɛmptəd ɡɹʌf kənvɪkʃən, bʌɾ ə hɪn ə kwɛstʃən hʌŋ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs.

"Are you all right, Mat?" Olver said. "Those Seanchan can't catch us." He attempted gruff conviction, but a hint of question hung in his voice.

əbɹʌpli mæt ɹilaɪzd i hæd bɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. ɛdʒiənɪn fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm waɪl fɪdlɪŋ æbsəntmaɪndɪdli wɪð əɹ wɪɡ, pleɪnli æŋɡɹi ðəɾ i wɑz ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hɝ. doʊmənz aɪz hæɾ ə stuɾiəs lʊk; ɪf i wɑz nɑt dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ tə bi əpsɛɾ ɑn ɛdʒiənɪnz bɪhæf, mæt wəɾ iɾ ɪz kæp. ivən θɛɹə wɑz pikɪŋ əɾ ɪm pæs ðə tɛns ɛntʃɹi flæp, ən ʃi ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə kip aʊɾ ʌv ɛdʒiənɪnz saɪt. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn. oʊnli ə mæn wɪð pɔɹədʒ fəɹ bɹeɪnz wəd bɪliv i ɡɑt wɔɹnɪŋz fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ daɪs noʊ wʌn kəd si. əɹ meɪbi ə mæn mɑɹk baɪ ðə paʊɝ. əɹ baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi wɑz nɑɾ æŋkʃəs tə hæv ɛni ʌv ðoʊz θɪŋz səspɛktəɾ əbaʊt hɪm. ən ɪt maɪt bi ðət naɪɾ ət ðə ɡeɪɾ ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn. noʊ, ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə sikɹəɾ i kɛɹd tə ɹɪvil. ɪt wəd də noʊ ɡʊd, ɛniweɪ. "ðeɪl nɛvɝ kætʃ ʌs, oʊlvɝ, nɑt jə ən mi." hi ɹʌfəl ðə bɔɪz hɛɹ, ən oʊlvɝ ɡeɪv ə waɪd-maʊðd ɡɹɪn, kɑnfəɾəns ɹɪstɔɹɾ əz izi əz ðæt. "nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz wi kip əɹ aɪz oʊpən ən əɹ wɪts əbaʊɾ ʌs. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jə kən faɪn ə weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɛni dɪfəkəlti ɪf jə kip jəɹ aɪz ən wɪts ʃɑɹp, bʌɾ ɪf jə doʊnt, jəl tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ jəɹ oʊn fit." oʊlvɝ nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪvli, bʌt mæt mɛn ðə ɹimaɪndɝ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz. əɹ meɪbi hɪmsɛlf. laɪt, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ ɛni ʌv əm kəd bi mɔɹ əlɝt. ɪksɛp fəɹ oʊlvɝ, hu θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ə ɡɹeɪɾ ædvɛntʃɝ, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bɪn dʒʌmpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ skɪnz sɪns bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi. "ɡoʊ hɛlp θɛɹə laɪk dʒulɪn toʊl ju, oʊlvɝ."

Abruptly Mat realized he had been staring at nothing. Egeanin frowned at him while fiddling absentmindedly with her wig, plainly angry that he was ignoring her. Domon's eyes had a studious look; if he was not deciding whether to be upset on Egeanin's behalf, Mat would eat his cap. Even Thera was peeking at him past the tent's entry flap, and she always tried to keep out of Egeanin's sight. He could not explain. Only a man with porridge for brains would believe he got warnings from hearing dice no one could see. Or maybe a man marked by the Power. Or by the Dark One. He was not anxious to have any of those things suspected about him. And it might be that night at the gate all over again. No, this was not a secret he cared to reveal. It would do no good, anyway. "They'll never catch us, Olver, not you and me." He ruffled the boy's hair, and Olver gave a wide-mouthed grin, confidence restored as easy as that. "Not so long as we keep our eyes open and our wits about us. Remember, you can find a way out of any difficulty if you keep your eyes and wits sharp, but if you don't, you'll trip over your own feet." Olver nodded gravely, but Mat meant the reminder for the others. Or maybe himself. Light, there was no way any of them could be more alert. Except for Olver, who thought it was all a great adventure, they had all been jumping out of their skins since before leaving the city. "Go help Thera like Juilin told you, Olver."

ə ʃɑɹp ɡʌs kʌt θɹu mæts koʊt, meɪkɪŋ ɪm ʃɪvɝ. "æn pʊt jəɹ koʊɾ ɑn; ɪts koʊld," hi æɾəd əz ðə bɔɪ dʌk pæs θɛɹə ɪndə ðə tɛnt. ɹʌsəlz ən skɹeɪpɪŋ saʊnz fɹəm ɪnsaɪd sɛd ðəɾ oʊlvɝ wɑz sɛɾɪŋ tə wɝk, wɪð əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɪz koʊt, bʌt θɛɹə ɹɪmeɪn kɹaʊtʃt ət ðə tɛns ɛntʃɹəns, piɹɪŋ ət mæt. fəɹ ɔl ðə kɛɹ ɛnibəɾi bʌt mæt kɔθən tʊk, ðə bɔɪ kəd kætʃ ɪz dɛθ.

A sharp gust cut through Mat's coat, making him shiver. "And put your coat on; it's cold," he added as the boy ducked past Thera into the tent. Rustles and scraping sounds from inside said that Olver was setting to work, with or without his coat, but Thera remained crouched at the tent's entrance, peering at Mat. For all the care anybody but Mat Cauthon took, the boy could catch his death.

əz sun əz oʊlvɝ dɪsəpɪɹd, ɛdʒiənɪn stɛp kloʊsɝ tə mæt, hɝ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps əɡɛn, ən i ɡɹoʊn ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. "wi ɑɹ gɑnə sɛɾəl mæɾɝz naʊ, kɔθən," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə hɑɹd vɔɪs.

As soon as Olver disappeared, Egeanin stepped closer to Mat, her fists on her hips again, and he groaned under his breath. "We are going to settle matters now, Cauthon," she said in a hard voice.

"naʊ! aɪ woʊn əv əɹ dʒɝni ɹɛk baɪ jə kaʊntɝməndɪŋ maɪ ɔɹɾɝz."

"Now! I won't have our journey wrecked by you countermanding my orders."

"ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə sɛɾəl," hi toʊl hɝ. "aɪ wɑz nɛvɝ jəɹ haɪɝd hænd, ən ðæts ðæt." sʌmhaʊ, hɝ feɪs mænədʒ tə ɡɹoʊ hɑɹɾɝ, əz ɡʊɾ əz ʃaʊɾɪŋ ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt si mæɾɝz laɪk ðæt. ðə wʊmən wɑz əz təneɪʃəs əz ə snæpɪŋ tɝɾəl, bʌt ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm weɪ tə pɹaɪ hɝ dʒɔz fɹəm ɪz lɛɡ. bɝn ɪm ɪf i wɑntəd tə bi əloʊn wɪð ðə daɪs ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, jɛt ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən hævɪŋ tə lɪsən tə ðɛm waɪl ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð hɝ. "aɪm gɑnə si tuɑn bɪfɔɹ wi liv." ðə wɝdz pɑpt aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ klɪɹ ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi ɹilaɪz ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn laɪɪŋ ðəɹ fəɹ səm taɪm, ðoʊ, mɝki ən sloʊli səlɪɾəfaɪɪŋ. ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɛdʒiənɪnz tʃiks əz sun əz tuɑnz neɪm lɛft ɪz maʊθ, ən i hɝɾ ə skwik fɹəm θɛɹə fɑloʊd baɪ ðə snæp ə ðə tɛntflæps biɪŋ dʒɝkt ʃʌt. ðə wʌntaɪm pɑnɑɹtʃ hæɾ əbzɔɹbd ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni sintʃæn weɪz waɪl ʃi wɑz sjuɹɔθs pɹɑpɝɾi, ən mɛni ʌv ðɛɹ tæbuz əz wɛl. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz meɪɾ ə hɑɹɾɝ stʌf, haʊɛvɝ. "waɪ?" ʃi dɪmændəd. ɪn ɔlmoʊs ðə seɪm bɹɛθ, ʃi wɛn ɑn, æŋkʃəs ən fjʊɹiəs ɔl ət wʌns. "ju mʌsnt kɔl əɹ ðæt. jə mʌst ʃoʊ ɹɪspɛkt." hɑɹɾɝ ɪn səm weɪz. mæt ɡɹɪnd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə si ðə dʒoʊk. ɹɪspɛkt? ðəɹ wɑz pɹɛʃəs lɪɾəl ɹɪspɛkt ɪn stʌfɪŋ ə ɡæɡ ɪn sʌmwʌnz maʊθ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ əm ʌp ɪn ə wɔl hæŋɪŋ. kɔlɪŋ tuɑn haɪ leɪɾi əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls wɑz nɑt gɑnə tʃeɪnʒ ðæt. ʌv kɔɹs, ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz mɔɹ wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk əbaʊt fɹiɪŋ deɪmeɪn ðən ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tuɑn. ɪf ʃi cʊɾə pɹitɛndəd ðə kɪdnæpɪŋ nɛvɝ hæpənd, ʃi wəd hæv, ən əz ɪt wɑz, ʃi tʃɹaɪd. laɪt, ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt waɪl ɪt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ɛni ʌðɝ kɹaɪmz ʃi maɪɾ əv kəmɪɾəd peɪl tə nʌθɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðæt. "bɪkɔz aɪ wɑnə tɔk wɪð hɝ," hi sɛd. ən waɪ nɑt? hi hæd tə, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ.

"There's nothing to settle," he told her. "I was never your hired hand, and that's that." Somehow, her face managed to grow harder, as good as shouting that she did not see matters like that. The woman was as tenacious as a snapping turtle, but there had to be some way to pry her jaws from his leg. Burn him if he wanted to be alone with the dice rolling in his head, yet that was better than having to listen to them while arguing with her. "I'm going to see Tuon before we leave." The words popped out of his mouth before they were clear in his head. He realized that they had been lying there for some time, though, murky and slowly solidifying. The blood drained from Egeanin's cheeks as soon as Tuon's name left his mouth, and he heard a squeak from Thera followed by the snap of the tentflaps being jerked shut. The onetime panarch had absorbed a great many Seanchan ways while she was Suroth's property, and many of their taboos as well. Egeanin was made of harder stuff, however. "Why?" she demanded. In almost the same breath, she went on, anxious and furious all at once. "You mustn't call her that. You must show respect." Harder in some ways. Mat grinned, but she did not seem to see the joke. Respect? There was precious little respect in stuffing a gag in someone's mouth and rolling them up in a wall hanging. Calling Tuon High Lady or anything else was not going to change that. Of course, Egeanin was more willing to talk about freeing damane than she was about Tuon. If she could have pretended the kidnapping never happened, she would have, and as it was, she tried. Light, she had tried to ignore it while it was happening. In her mind, any other crimes she might have committed paled to nothing beside that. "Because I want to talk with her," he said. And why not? He had to, sooner or later.

pipəl hæd bɪɡʌn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹit, naʊ, hæf-dʒɹɛs mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ ʃɝts hæŋɪŋ aʊɾ ən wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ hɛɹ stɪl ɹæpt ɪn naɪt-kɝtʃəfs, səm liɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz ən ʌðɝz dʒʌs mɪlɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz fɑɹ əz i kəd meɪk aʊt. ə wɪɹi bɔɪ ə lɪɾəl bɪɡɝ ðən oʊlvɝ wɛn pæs duɪŋ hændspɹɪŋz wɛɹɛvɝ ðə kɹaʊd ɡeɪv ɪm ə peɪs ə ɹum, pɹæktəsɪŋ əɹ meɪbi pleɪɪŋ. ðə slipi fɛloʊ ɪn ðə dip ɡɹin wæɡən stɪl hæd nɑɾ əpɪɹd. lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ wəd nɑt bi tʃɹævlɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ fəɹ aʊɝz jɛt. ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv taɪm. "ju kəd kʌm wɪð mi," hi sədʒɛstəɾ ɪn ɪz moʊst ɪnəsən vɔɪs. hi ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ə ðɪs bɪfɔɹ.

People had begun trotting up and down the narrow street, now, half-dressed men with their shirts hanging out and women with their hair still wrapped in night-kerchiefs, some leading horses and others just milling about as far as he could make out. A wiry boy a little bigger than Olver went past doing handsprings wherever the crowd gave him a pace of room, practicing or maybe playing. The sleepy fellow in the deep green wagon still had not appeared. Luca's Grand Traveling Show would not be traveling anywhere for hours yet. There was plenty of time. "You could come with me," he suggested in his most innocent voice. He should have thought of this before.

ði ɪnvɪteɪʃən meɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ɡoʊ fɛns-poʊst stɪf fəɹ tʃɹu. ɪt hɑɹdli sim pɑsəbəl əɹ feɪs kəd ɡɹoʊ ɛni pəlɝ, bʌɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə skɹæp ə kʌlɝ litʃt aʊt. "ju wɪl ʃoʊ hɝ fɪɾɪŋ ɹɪspɛkt," ʃi sɛd hɔɹsli, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə nɑɾɪd skɑɹf wɪð boʊθ hænz əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə skwiz ðə blæk wɪɡ taɪɾɝ ɑntu hɝ hɛd. "kʌm, beɪl. aɪ wɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ maɪ θɪŋz ɑɹ stoʊd pɹɑpɝli." doʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ʃi tɝn ən hɝiɾ əweɪ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk, ən mæt wɑtʃt ɪm wɛɹəli. hi hæd veɪɡ mɛmɹiz ʌv ə flaɪɾ ɑn dimənz ɹɪvɝʃɪp, wʌns, bʌt veɪɡ wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd seɪ ʌv ðɛm. tɑm wɑz fɹɛnli wɪð doʊmən, ə pɔɪn ɪn ði ɪliɑnɝz feɪvɝ, jɛɾ i wɑz ɛdʒiənɪnz mæn tə ðə naɪf, ɹɛɾi tə bæk əɹ ɑn ɛniθɪŋ daʊn tə dɪsləkɪŋ dʒulɪn, ən mæt tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɪm noʊ fɝðɝ ðən i dɪd hɝ. wɪtʃ wɑz tə seɪ, nɑt vɛɹi fɑɹ. ɛdʒiənɪn ən doʊmən hæd ðɛɹ oʊn ɡoʊlz, ən wɛðɝ mæt kɔθən kɛpt ə hoʊl haɪd dɪd nɑt fæktɝ ɪn ðɛm. hi daʊɾɪd ðət ðə mæn ɹɪli tʃɹʌstɪd hɪm, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, bʌt ðɛn, niðɝ ə ðɛm hæd mʌtʃ tʃɔɪs ət ðə moʊmənt. "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi," doʊmən mʌɾɝd, skɹætʃɪŋ ðə bɹɪsəlz ɡɹoʊɪŋ əbʌv ɪz lɛft ɪɹ, "wʌtɛvɝ jə də bi ʌp tə, jə meɪ bi ɪn oʊvɝ jəɹ hɛd. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi də bi tʌfɝ ðən jə də səspɛkt." "ɛdʒiənɪn?" mæt sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn kwɪkli tə si wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn ɪn ði æli hæd hɝɾ ɪz slɪp. ə fju ɡlænst əɾ ɪm ən doʊmən əz ðeɪ bɹʌʃt baɪ, bʌt noʊbɑdi ɡlæns twaɪs. lukə wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn iɡɝ tə bi ɡɔn fɹəm ə sɪɾi wɛɹ ðə floʊ ʌv peɪtʃɹənz fəɹ ðə ʃoʊ hæd dʒɹaɪɾ ʌp ən naɪt laɪtnɪŋ sɛɾɪŋ ðə hɑɹbɝ ɑn faɪɝ wɑz ə fɹɛʃ mɛmɹi. ðeɪ maɪɾ ɔl əv flɛd ðət fɝs naɪt, livɪŋ mæt noʊwɛɹ tə haɪd, ɪksɛp fəɹ lukə ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. ðət pɹɑməst ɡoʊl hæd meɪd lukə vɛɹi pɝsweɪsɪv. "aɪ noʊ ʃiz tʌfɝ ðən oʊl buts, doʊmən, bʌɾ oʊl buts doʊn kaʊnt wɪð mi. ðɪs ɪzən ə blʌɾi ʃɪp, ən aɪm nɑt lɛɾɪŋ əɹ teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ən ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ." doʊmən ɡɹɪməst əz ɪf mæt wɝ ɡus-bɹeɪnd. "ðə ɡɝl, mæn. dʒju bɪliv jə kəd bi soʊ kɑm ɪf jə dɪd bi kæɹiɾ ɔf ɪn ðə naɪt? wʌtɛvɝ jə bi pleɪɪŋ æt, wɪð ðət waɪl tɔk ə hɝ biɪŋ jəɹ waɪf, hæv ə kɛɹ əɹ ʃi meɪ ʃeɪv jəɹ hɛɾ ət ðə ʃoʊldɝz."

The invitation made Egeanin go fence-post stiff for true. It hardly seemed possible her face could grow any paler, but an extra scrap of color leached out. "You will show her fitting respect," she said hoarsely, clutching the knotted scarf with both hands as though trying to squeeze the black wig tighter onto her head. "Come, Bayle. I want to make sure my things are stowed properly." Domon hesitated as she turned and hurried away into the crowd without looking back, and Mat watched him warily. He had vague memories of a flight on Demon's rivership, once, but vague was the best he could say of them. Thom was friendly with Domon, a point in the Illianer's favor, yet he was Egeanin's man to the knife, ready to back her on anything down to disliking Juilin, and Mat trusted him no further than he did her. Which was to say, not very far. Egeanin and Domon had their own goals, and whether Mat Cauthon kept a whole hide did not factor in them. He doubted that the man really trusted him, for that matter, but then, neither of them had much choice at the moment. "Fortune prick me," Domon muttered, scratching the bristles growing above his left ear, "whatever you do be up to, you may be in over your head. I think she do be tougher than you do suspect." "Egeanin?" Mat said incredulously. He looked around quickly to see whether anyone in the alley had heard his slip. A few glanced at him and Domon as they brushed by, but nobody glanced twice. Luca was not the only one eager to be gone from a city where the flow of patrons for the show had dried up and night lightning setting the harbor on fire was a fresh memory. They might all have fled that first night, leaving Mat nowhere to hide, except for Luca arguing them out of it. That promised gold had made Luca very persuasive. "I know she's tougher than old boots, Domon, but old boots don't count with me. This isn't a bloody ship, and I'm not letting her take charge and ruin everything." Domon grimaced as if Mat were goose-brained. "The girl, man. Do you believe you could be so calm if you did be carried off in the night? Whatever you be playing at, with that wild talk of her being your wife, have a care or she may shave your head at the shoulders."

"aɪ wɑz dʒʌs kʌɾɪŋ ðə ful," mæt mʌɾɝd. "haʊ mɛni taɪmz də aɪ hæv tə seɪ ɪt? aɪ wɑz ənnɝv fəɹ ə mɪnət." oʊ, hi hæd bɪn ðæt. lɝnɪŋ u tuɑn wɑz, waɪl i wɑz ɹɛslɪŋ wɪð hɝ, wʊɾə ənnɝvd ə blʌɾi tʃɹɑlɑk.

"I was just cutting the fool," Mat muttered. "How many times do I have to say it? I was unnerved for a minute." Oh, he had been that. Learning who Tuon was, while he was wrestling with her, would have unnerved a bloody Trolloc.

doʊmən ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. wɛl, ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ðə bɛst stɔɹi mæt hæɾ ɛvɝ kʌm ʌp wɪð. ɪksɛp fəɹ doʊmən, ɛvɹiwʌn u hæd hɝɾ ɪm bæbəlɪŋ sim tə æksɛp ðə teɪl, ðoʊ. mæt θɔt ðeɪ hæd, ɛniweɪ. ɛdʒiənɪn maɪt ɡɛɾ ə nɑɾ ɪn əɹ tʌŋ ət ðə vɛɹi θɔɾ ə tuɑn, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə sɛd plɛnti ɪf ʃi bɪlivd i hæd bɪn sɪɹiəs. laɪkli ʃi wʊɾə pʊɾ əɹ naɪf ɪn hɪm.

Domon grunted in disbelief. Well, it was hardly the best story Mat had ever come up with. Except for Domon, everyone who had heard him babbling seemed to accept the tale, though. Mat thought they had, anyway. Egeanin might get a knot in her tongue at the very thought of Tuon, but she would have said plenty if she believed he had been serious. Likely she would have put her knife in him.

pikɪŋ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ɛdʒiənɪn hæd ɡɔn, ði ɪliɑnɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "tʃɹaɪ tə kip ə ɡɹɪp ɑn jəɹ tʌŋ fɹəm naʊ ɑn. ɛɡ - . . . laɪlwɪn . . . də nɪɹ əv ə fɪt wɛnɛvɝ ʃi də θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt jə dɪd seɪ. aɪv hɝɾ əɹ mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ən jə kən weɪdʒɝ ðə ɡɝl hɝsɛlf dʌz teɪk ɪt noʊ laɪɾɝ. jə 'kʌt ðə ful' wɪð hɝ, ən jə meɪ ɡɛɾ əs ɔl ʃɔɹɾənd." hi slɪɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ əkɹɔs ɪz θɹoʊɾ ɪkspɹɛsɪvli ən ɡeɪv ə kɝt nɑd bɪfɔɹ pʊʃɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ æftɝ ɛdʒiənɪn.

Peeking in the direction Egeanin had gone, the Illianer shook his head. "Try to keep a grip on your tongue from now on. Eg - . . . Leilwin . . . do near have a fit whenever she do think about what you did say. I've heard her muttering under her breath, and you can wager the girl herself does take it no lighter. You 'cut the fool' with her, and you may get us all shortened." He slid a finger across his throat expressively and gave a curt nod before pushing through the crowd after Egeanin.

wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ, mæt ʃʊk ɪz oʊn hɛd. tuɑn, tʌf? tʃɹu, ʃi wɑz ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ən ɔl ə ðæt, ən ʃi hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ ʌndɝ ɪz skɪn wɪð ə lʊk bæk ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, wən i θɔt ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ sintʃæn noʊbəlwʊmən wɪð əɹ noʊz ɪn ði ɛɹ, bʌt ðət wɑz dʒʌs kəz ʃi kɛp tɝnɪŋ ʌp wɛɹ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. tʌf? ʃi lʊk laɪk ə dɑl meɪɾ ə blæk pɔɹsələn. haʊ tʌf kəd ʃi bi? ɪt wɑz ɔl jə kəd də tə kip əɹ fɹəm bɹeɪkɪŋ jəɹ noʊz ən meɪbi mɔɹ, hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf.

Watching him go, Mat shook his own head. Tuon, tough? True, she was the Daughter of the Nine Moons and all of that, and she had been able to get under his skin with a look back in the Tarasin Palace, when he thought she was just another Seanchan noblewoman with her nose in the air, but that was just because she kept turning up where he did not expect. No more than that. Tough? She looked like a doll made of black porcelain. How tough could she be? It was all you could do to keep her from breaking your nose and maybe more, he reminded himself.

hi hæd bɪn kɛɹfəl nɑt tə ɹɪpit wʌt doʊmən kɔld "waɪl tɔk," bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ ʌv ɪt wɑz, hi wɑz gɑnə mɛɹi tuɑn. ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪm saɪ. hi nu ɪɾ əz ʃʊɹ əz pɹɑfəsi, wɪtʃ ɪt wɑz, ɪn ə weɪ. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən haʊ sətʃ ə mɛɹɪdʒ kəd kʌm əbaʊt; ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl, ɑn ðə feɪs ʌv ɪt, ən i wəd nɑt wip ɪf ðət pɹuv tə bi soʊ. bʌɾ i nu ɪt wəd nɑt. waɪ dɪɾ i ɔlweɪz faɪn hɪmsɛlf blʌɾi lʌmbɝd wɪð blʌɾi wɪmən u pʊl naɪvz ɑn ɪm əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə kɪk ɪz hɛɾ ɔf? ɪt wɑz nɑt fɛɹ.

He had been careful not to repeat what Domon called "wild talk," but the truth of it was, he was going to marry Tuon. The thought made him sigh. He knew it as sure as prophecy, which it was, in a way. He could not imagine how such a marriage could come about; it seemed impossible, on the face of it, and he would not weep if that proved to be so. But he knew it would not. Why did he always find himself bloody lumbered with bloody women who pulled knives on him or tried to kick his head off? It was not fair.

hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ stʃɹeɪt tə ðə wæɡən wɛɹ tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə wɝ biɪŋ kɛpt, wɪð sɛɾəl ɑnən tə wɑtʃ - ði ɪnkipɝ kəd meɪk ə stoʊn sim sɑft; ə pæmpɝd noʊbəlwʊmən ən ə leɪɾiz meɪd wəd ɡɪv əɹ noʊ tʃɹʌbəl, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ə ɹɛdɑɹm ɑn duɾi aʊtsaɪd. ət list, ðeɪ hæd nɑt soʊ fɑɹ, əɹ i wʊɾə hɝd - bʌɾ i faʊn ɪz fit wɑndɝɪŋ, teɪkɪŋ ɪm əlɔŋ ðə waɪndɪŋ stʃɹits ðət ɹæn θɹu ðə ʃoʊ. bʌsəl fɪld ɔl ə ðɛm, waɪɾ ən nɛɹoʊ əlaɪk. mɛn ɹʌʃt baɪ liɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz ðət fɹɪskt ən ʃaɪd, tu lɔŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛksɝsaɪz. ʌðɝ pipəl wɝ teɪkɪŋ daʊn tɛns ən pækɪŋ ðə stɔɹədʒ wæɡənz, əɹ hɔlɪŋ klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəlz ən bɹæs-baʊn tʃɛsts ən kæsks ən kænəstɝz ʌv ɛvɹi saɪz aʊɾ ə ðə haʊs-laɪk wæɡənz ðət hæd bɪn stændɪŋ hɪɹ fəɹ mʌnθs, pɑɹʃəli ənloʊɾɪŋ soʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd bi ɹipæk fəɹ tʃɹævəl ivən waɪl ðə timz wɝ biɪŋ hɑɹnəst. ðə dɪn wɑz kɑnstənt: hɔɹsəz wɪkɝd, wɪmən ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, tʃɪlʒɹən kɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ lɔs tɔɪz əɹ jɛl fəɹ ðə pjʊɹ plɛʒɝ ə nɔɪz, mɛn bɛloʊd tə noʊ hu hæd bɪn ət ðɛɹ hɑɹnəs əɹ u hæd bɑɹoʊd səm tul. ə tʃɹup ʌv ækɹəbæts, slɛndɝ bʌt mʌskjəlɝ wɪmən u wɝkt ɑn ɹoʊps dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm tɔl poʊlz, hæd sɝaʊndəd wʌn ə ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz, ɔl ə ðɛm weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən ɡɪvɪŋ vɔɪs ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz ən noʊbɑdi lɪsnɪŋ. mæt pɔzd ə moʊmən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ, bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli hi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ʃʊɹ ðɛmsɛlvz. tu faɪɾɪŋ koʊtləs mɛn ɹoʊld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɑtʃt kloʊsli baɪ ðə laɪkli kɑz, ə wɪləwi hɑt-aɪd simstʃɹɪs neɪm dʒəmaɪn, bʌt pɛtʃɹə əpɪɹɾ ən pʊld əm əpɑɹt bɪfɔɹ mæt kəɾ ivən ɡɛɾ ə bɛt daʊn.

He intended to go straight to the wagon where Tuon and Selucia were being kept, with Setalle Anan to watch - the innkeeper could make a stone seem soft; a pampered noblewoman and a lady's maid would give her no trouble, especially with a Redarm on duty outside. At least, they had not so far, or he would have heard - but he found his feet wandering, taking him along the winding streets that ran through the show. Bustle filled all of them, wide and narrow alike. Men rushed by leading horses that frisked and shied, too long without exercise. Other people were taking down tents and packing the storage wagons, or hauling cloth-wrapped bundles and brass-bound chests and casks and canisters of every size out of the house-like wagons that had been standing here for months, partially unloading so everything could be repacked for travel even while the teams were being harnessed. The din was constant: horses whickered, women shouted for children, children cried over lost toys or yelled for the pure pleasure of noise, men bellowed to know who had been at their harness or who had borrowed some tool. A troupe of acrobats, slender but muscular women who worked on ropes dangling from tall poles, had surrounded one of the horse handlers, all of them waving their arms and giving voice at the top of their lungs and nobody listening. Mat paused a moment trying to figure out what they were arguing over, but eventually he decided they were not sure themselves. Two fighting coatless men rolled on the ground, watched closely by the likely cause, a willowy hot-eyed seamstress named Jameine, but Petra appeared and pulled them apart before Mat could even get a bet down.

hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə siɪŋ tuɑn əɡɛn. ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. hi hæd steɪɾ əweɪ, æftɝ stɪkɪŋ əɹ ɪndə ðət wæɡən, tə ɡɪv əɹ taɪm tə sɛɾəl daʊn ən kəlɛk hɝsɛlf. ðət wɑz ɔl. oʊnli. . . . kɑm, doʊmən hæd kɔl hɝ, ən ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. kɪdnæpt ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt, snætʃt aʊɾ ɪndə ə stɔɹm baɪ pipəl u wəɾ əz sun əv kʌɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ əz lʊk ət hɝ, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi nu, ən ʃi hæd bɪn baɪ fɑɹ ðə kuləst ə ðɛm ɔl. laɪt, ʃi cʊɾə plæn ɪt hɝsɛlf, ðət wɑz haʊ ʌpsɛt ʃi wɑz! ɪt hæd meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə naɪf wɝ tɪklɪŋ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz ðɛn, ən ðə naɪf wɑz bæk əɡɛn dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ. ən ðoʊz daɪs wɝ ɹætlɪŋ əweɪ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl.

He was not afraid of seeing Tuon again. Of course not. He had stayed away, after sticking her into that wagon, to give her time to settle down and collect herself. That was all. Only. . . . Calm, Domon had called her, and it was true. Kidnapped in the middle of the night, snatched out into a storm by people who would as soon have cut her throat as look at her, as far as she knew, and she had been by far the coolest of them all. Light, she could have planned it herself, that was how upset she was! It had made him feel as if the point of a knife were tickling between his shoulder blades then, and the knife was back again just thinking about her. And those dice were rattling away inside his skull.

ðə wʊmənz hɑɹdli laɪkli tə ɔfɝ tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ vaʊz hɪɹ ən naʊ, hi θɔt wɪð ə tʃʌkəl, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd fɔɹst ivən tə hɪm. jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən ʌndɝ ðə sʌn fəɹ ɪm tə bi əfɹeɪd. hi wɑz dʒʌs pɹɑpɝli wɛɹi, nɑɾ əfɹeɪd.

The woman's hardly likely to offer to exchange vows here and now, he thought with a chuckle, but it sounded forced even to him. Yet there was no reason under the sun for him to be afraid. He was just properly wary, not afraid.

ðə ʃoʊ maɪɾ əv ikwəld ə fɛɹ-saɪz vɪlədʒ fəɹ saɪz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli soʊ lɔŋ ə mæn kəd wɑndɝ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðət mʌtʃ speɪs bɪfɔɹ i stɑɹɾəd dʌbəlɪŋ bæk ɑn hɪmsɛlf. sun ɪnʌf, tu sun, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə wɪndoʊləs wæɡən peɪntəɾ ɪn feɪɾəd pɝpəl, sɝaʊndəd baɪ kænvəs-tɑp stɔɹədʒ wæɡənz ən ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə sʌðɝnmoʊs hɔɹslaɪnz. ðə dʌŋ kɑɹts hæd nɑt ɡɔn aʊt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ði oʊɾɝ wɑz stʃɹɔŋ. ðə wɪn kæɹiɾ ə hɛvi sɛn fɹəm ðə nɪɹəst ænəməl keɪdʒɪz, tu, ə mʌski smɛl ə bɪɡ kæts ən bɛɹz ən ðə laɪt nu wʌɾ ɛls. bɪɑn ðə stɔɹədʒ wæɡənz ən pɪkəts, ə sɛkʃən ə ðə kænvəs wɔl fɛl ən ənʌðɝ bɪɡæn tə ʃeɪk əz mɛn lusən ðə ɡaɪ ɹoʊps hoʊldɪŋ ðə poʊlz. ðə sʌn, hæf-hɪɾən baɪ dɑɹk klaʊdz naʊ, hæd klaɪm hæfweɪ tə ɪts nundeɪ pik əɹ bɛɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl tu sun. hɑɹnən ən mɛtwɪn, tu ʌv ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪtʃt ðə fɝs pɛɹ ə hɔɹsəz tə ðə ʃæft ə ðə pɝpəl wæɡən ən wɝ ɔlmoʊs dʌn wɪð ðə sɛkən pɛɹ. soʊlʒɝz wɛl tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd, ðeɪ wəd bi ɹɛɾi tə teɪk ðə ɹoʊd waɪl ðə ʃoʊfoʊk wɝ stɪl fɪɡjɝɪŋ aʊt wɪtʃ weɪ ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ səpoʊz tə feɪs. mæt hæd tɔt ðə bæn tə muv fæst wən ðəɹ wɑz nid. hɪz oʊn fit dʒɹæɡd əz ðoʊ hi wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn mʌd. hɑɹnən, wɪð ðət ful tætu ʌv ə hɔk ɑn ɪz tʃik, wɑz ðə fɝs tə si hɪm. bʌklɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪs, ðə hɛvi-dʒɔd faɪl-liɾɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð mɛtwɪn, ə bɔɪɪʃ-feɪs kɛɹhinɪn huz əpɪɹəns bɪlaɪɾ ɪz eɪdʒ ən ɪz wiknəs fəɹ tævɝn bɹɔlz. ðeɪ hæd noʊ kɔl tə lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd.

The show might have equaled a fair-sized village for size, but there was only so long a man could wander about in that much space before he started doubling back on himself. Soon enough, too soon, he found himself staring at a windowless wagon painted in faded purple, surrounded by canvas-topped storage wagons and in sight of the southernmost horselines. The dung carts had not gone out this morning, and the odor was strong. The wind carried a heavy scent from the nearest animal cages, too, a musky smell of big cats and bears and the Light knew what else. Beyond the storage wagons and pickets, a section of the canvas wall fell and another began to shake as men loosened the guy ropes holding the poles. The sun, half-hidden by dark clouds now, had climbed halfway to its noonday peak or better, but it was still too soon. Harnan and Metwyn, two of the Redarms, had already hitched the first pair of horses to the shaft of the purple wagon and were almost done with the second pair. Soldiers well trained in the Band of the Red Hand, they would be ready to take the road while the showfolk were still figuring out which way the horses were supposed to face. Mat had taught the Band to move fast when there was need. His own feet dragged as though he were wading in mud. Harnan, with that fool tattoo of a hawk on his cheek, was the first to see him. Buckling a trace, the heavy-jawed file-leader exchanged looks with Metwyn, a boyish-faced Cairhienin whose appearance belied his age and his weakness for tavern brawls. They had no call to look surprised.

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡoʊɪŋ smuðli? aɪ wɑnə bi əweɪ ɪn ɡʊd taɪm." ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ əɡɛns ðə koʊld, mæt aɪd ðə pɝpəl wæɡən ənizəli. hi ʃʊɾə bɹɔɾ əɹ ə pɹɛzənt, dʒuəlɹi əɹ flaʊɝz. iðɝ wɝkt əz wɛl, wɪð moʊst wɪmən. "smuð ɪnʌf, maɪ lɔɹd," hɑɹnən ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə kɔʃəs toʊn. "noʊ ʃaʊɾɪŋ, noʊ skɹimɪŋ, noʊ kɹaɪɪŋ." hi ɡlænst ət ðə wæɡən əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt kɹɛɾət ɪt hɪmsɛlf.

"Everything going smoothly? I want to be away in good time." Rubbing his hands together against the cold, Mat eyed the purple wagon uneasily. He should have brought her a present, jewelry or flowers. Either worked as well, with most women. "Smooth enough, my Lord," Harnan replied in a cautious tone. "No shouting, no screaming, no crying." He glanced at the wagon as if he did not credit it himself.

"kwaɪət suts mi," mɛtwɪn sɛd, stʃɹɪŋɪŋ wʌn ə ðə ɹeɪnz θɹu ə ɹɪŋ ɑn ə hɔɹs-kɑlɝ.

"Quiet suits me," Metwyn said, stringing one of the reins through a ring on a horse-collar.

"wʊmən stɑɹts kɹaɪɪŋ, ði oʊnli θɪŋ tə də ɪz liv, ɪf jə vælju jəɹ haɪd, ən wi kən hɑɹdli dʒɹɑp ðiz ɔf baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd." bʌɾ i ɡlænst ət ðə wæɡən, tu, ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif.

"Woman starts crying, the only thing to do is leave, if you value your hide, and we can hardly drop these off by the side of the road." But he glanced at the wagon, too, and shook his head in disbelief.

ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ mæt tə də ɪksɛpt ɡoʊ ɪnsaɪd. soʊ hi dɪd. ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk tu tʃɹaɪz, wɪð ə smaɪl fɪkst ɑn ɪz feɪs, tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf klaɪm ðə ʃɔɹt flaɪɾ ə peɪntəd wʊɾən stɛps ət ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, bʌɾ ɛni ful wəd noʊ ɪnʌf tə bi nɝvəs.

There really was nothing for Mat to do except go inside. So he did. It only took two tries, with a smile fixed on his face, to make himself climb the short flight of painted wooden steps at the back of the wagon. He was not afraid, but any fool would know enough to be nervous.

dɪspaɪt ðə læk ʌv wɪndoʊz, ði ɪntɪɹiɝ ə ðə wæɡən wɑz wɛl laɪɾəd, wɪð fɔɹ mɪɹɝd læmps bɝnɪŋ, ən ðə læmps hɛld ɡʊɾ ɔɪl, soʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹænsɪd smɛl. bʌt ðɛn, wɪð ðə stɪŋk fɹəm aʊtsaɪd, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn hɑɹd tə tɛl. hi niɾəd tə faɪn ə bɛɾɝ spɑt tə pɑɹk ɪz wæɡən. ə smɔl bɹɪk stoʊv wɪð ən aɪɝn dɔɹ, ən ən aɪɝn tɑp fəɹ kʊkɪŋ, meɪd ðə speɪs toʊsti kəmpɛɹd wɪð aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə lɑɹdʒ wæɡən, ən ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ʌv wɔl ðət kəd bi spɛɹd wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð kæbənəts əɹ ʃɛlvz əɹ pɛɡz fəɹ hæŋɪŋ kloʊðɪŋ ən taʊəlz ən ðə laɪk, bʌt ðə teɪbəl ðət kəd bi lɛt daʊn ɑn ɹoʊps wɑz snʌɡ əɡɛns ðə silɪŋ, ən ðə θɹi wɪmən ɪnsaɪd ðə wæɡən wɝ hɑɹdli kɹaʊɾəd. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ dɪfɹənt, ðoʊz θɹi. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə ðə tu nɛɹoʊ bɛdz bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔlz, ə ɹiɡəl wʊmən wɪð tʌtʃəz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, simɪŋli ɪntɛn ɑn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ən nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɔl əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə ɡɑɹd. ə lɑɹdʒ ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋ hʌŋ ɪn itʃ ə hɝ ɪɹz, ən əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf dæŋɡəl fɹəm ə kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ sɪlvɝ nɛkləs, ðə hɪlt wɪð ɪts ɹɛɾ ən waɪt stoʊnz snʌɡ ɪn ðə klivədʒ ɪkspoʊz baɪ ðə nɛɹoʊ plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklaɪn ə hɝ ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs ðət hæd wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə skɝt soʊn ʌp tə ɪkspoʊz jɛloʊ pɛɾikoʊts. ʃi wɔɹ ənʌðɝ naɪf, wɪð ə lɔŋ, kɝv bleɪd, tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, bʌt ðət wɑz dʒʌs ðə kʌstəm ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. sɛɾəl hæd ɹəfjuz tə teɪk ɑn ɛni dɪsɡaɪz, wɪtʃ simd wɛl ɪnʌf. noʊ wʌn hæd ɹizən tə bi hʌntɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, ən faɪndɪŋ kloʊðz fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls hæd bɪn ə bɪɡ ɪnʌf pɹɑbləm əz ɪt wɑz. sɪlutʃə, ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð skɪn ðə kʌlɝ ə bʌɾɝi kɹim, wɑz kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ bɪtwin ðə bɛdz, ə dɑɹk skɑɹf kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ ʃeɪvən hɛɾ ən ə sʌlən ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs, ðoʊ nɔɹməli ʃi wɑz dɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən lʊk flaɪɾi. hɝ aɪz wɝ əz blu əz ɛdʒiənɪnz, ən mɔɹ pɪɹsɪŋ, ən ʃi hæd meɪd mɔɹ fʌs ðən ɛdʒiənɪn oʊvɝ luzɪŋ əɹ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ hɛɹ. ʃi dɪslaɪk ðə dɑɹk blu ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɪvən, tu, kleɪmɪŋ ðə dip nɛklaɪn wɑz ɪndisənt, bʌɾ ɪt hɪɾ əɹ əz ɪfɛktɪvli əz ə mæsk. fju mɛn u ɡlɪmpst sɪlutʃəz ɪmpɹɛsɪv bʊzəm wəd bi eɪbəl tə foʊkəs lɔŋ ɑn əɹ feɪs. mæt maɪɾ əv ɛndʒɔɪd ðə vju fəɹ ə eɪ ɛf eɪ ɛn ə si oʊ ɛl oʊ ɑɹ ɛs wʌnhʌnʒɹədθɝdisɛvən moʊmən əɹ tu hɪmsɛlf, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz tuɑn, siɾəd ɑn ðə wæɡənz oʊnli stul, ə lɛðɝ-baʊn bʊk oʊpən ɑn əɹ læp, ən i kəd bɛɹli meɪk hɪmsɛlf lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. hɪz waɪf-tə-bi. laɪt! tuɑn wɑz taɪni, nɑt dʒʌst ʃɔɹt bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst slɪm əz ə bɔɪ, ən ə lus-fɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ə bɹaʊn wʊl, bɑt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə ʃoʊfoʊk, meɪɾ əɹ sim ə tʃaɪld wɛɹɪŋ əɹ oʊldɝ sɪstɝz kloʊðz. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊmən i ɛndʒɔɪd, ɪspɛʃli wɪð oʊnli ə fju deɪz' ɡɹoʊθ ə blæk stʌbəl kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ skælp. ɪf jə ɪɡnɔɹd ðæt, ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ðoʊ, ɪn ə ɹɪzɝvd weɪ, wɪð əɹ hɑɹt-ʃeɪp feɪs ən fʊl lɪps, hɝ aɪz lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk lɪkwəd pulz ə sɝɛnəɾi. ðəɾ ʌɾɝ kɑmnəs ɔlmoʊst ənnɝv hɪm. nɑɾ ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi sɝin ɪn əɹ sɝkəmstænsəz. ðə blʌɾi daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd dɪd nɑt hɛlp mæɾɝz.

Despite the lack of windows, the interior of the wagon was well lighted, with four mirrored lamps burning, and the lamps held good oil, so there was no rancid smell. But then, with the stink from outside, it would have been hard to tell. He needed to find a better spot to park his wagon. A small brick stove with an iron door, and an iron top for cooking, made the space toasty compared with outside. It was not a large wagon, and every inch of wall that could be spared was covered with cabinets or shelves or pegs for hanging clothing and towels and the like, but the table that could be let down on ropes was snug against the ceiling, and the three women inside the wagon were hardly crowded. They could not have been more different, those three. Mistress Anan was sitting on one of the two narrow beds built into the walls, a regal woman with touches of gray in her hair, seemingly intent on her embroidery hoop and not looking at all as if she were a guard. A large golden ring hung in each of her ears, and her marriage knife dangled from a close-fitting silver necklace, the hilt with its red and white stones snug in the cleavage exposed by the narrow plunging neckline of her Ebou Dari dress that had one side of the skirt sewn up to expose yellow petticoats. She wore another knife, with a long, curved blade, tucked behind her belt, but that was just the custom of Ebou Dar. Setalle had refused to take on any disguise, which seemed well enough. No one had reason to be hunting for her, and finding clothes for everyone else had been a big enough problem as it was. Selucia, a pretty woman with skin the color of buttery cream, was cross-legged on the floor between the beds, a dark scarf covering her shaven head and a sullen expression on her face, though normally she was dignified enough to make Mistress Anan look flighty. Her eyes were as blue as Egeanin's, and more piercing, and she had made more fuss than Egeanin over losing her the rest of her hair. She disliked the dark blue Ebou Dari dress she had been given, too, claiming the deep neckline was indecent, but it hid her as effectively as a mask. Few men who glimpsed Selucia's impressive bosom would be able to focus long on her face. Mat might have enjoyed the view for a A F A N OF C O L O R S 137 moment or two himself, but there was Tuon, seated on the wagon's only stool, a leather-bound book open on her lap, and he could barely make himself look at anything else. His wife-to-be. Light! Tuon was tiny, not just short but almost slim as a boy, and a loose-fitting dress of brown wool, bought from one of the showfolk, made her seem a child wearing her older sister's clothes. Not at all the sort of woman he enjoyed, especially with only a few days' growth of black stubble covering her scalp. If you ignored that, she was pretty, though, in a reserved way, with her heart-shaped face and full lips, her eyes large dark liquid pools of serenity. That utter calmness almost unnerved him. Not even an Aes Sedai would be serene in her circumstances. The bloody dice in his head did not help matters.

"sɛɾəl əz bɪn kipɪŋ mi ɪnfɔɹmd," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kul dʒɹɔl əz i pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt. hi hæd ɡɑɾən soʊ hi kəd tɛl ə dɪfɝəns ɪn sintʃæn æksɛns; tuɑnz meɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪn saʊn əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə maʊθfʊl ə mʌʃ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl saʊndəd slɝɾ ən sloʊ. "ʃiz toʊl mi ðə stɔɹi juv pʊɾ əbaʊt kənsɝnɪŋ mi, tɔɪ."

"Setalle has been keeping me informed," she said in a cool drawl as he pulled the door shut. He had gotten so he could tell a difference in Seanchan accents; Tuon's made Egeanin sound as if she had a mouthful of mush, but they all sounded slurred and slow. "She's told me the story you have put about concerning me, Toy."

tuɑn hæd pɝsɪstəɾ ɪn kɔlɪŋ ɪm ðæt, bæk ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. hi hæd nɑt kɛɹd, ðɛn. wɛl, nɑt mʌtʃ.

Tuon had persisted in calling him that, back in the Tarasin Palace. He had not cared, then. Well, not much.

"maɪ neɪm ɪz mæt," hi bɪɡæn. hi nɛvɝ sɔ wɛɹ ðə pɑɾɝi kʌp ɪn əɹ hæn keɪm fɹʌm, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə dʒɹɑp tə ðə flɔɹ ɪn taɪm fəɹ ɪt tə ʃæɾɝ əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ ɪnstɛɾ ə hɪz hɛd. "aɪ æm ə sɝvənt, tɔɪ?" ɪf tuɑnz toʊn hæd bɪn kul bɪfɔɹ, naʊ ɪt wɑz dip wɪntɝ aɪs. ʃi bɛɹli ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾ əz aɪs, tu. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wʊɾə meɪɾ ə hæŋɪŋ dʒʌdʒ lʊk ɡɪɾi. "ə θivɪŋ sɝvənt?" ðə bʊk slɪd fɹəm əɹ læp əz ʃi stʊɾ ən bɛn tə snætʃ ʌp ðə lɪɾɪd waɪt tʃeɪmbɝ pɑt.

"My name is Mat," he began. He never saw where the pottery cup in her hand came from, but he managed to drop to the floor in time for it to shatter against the door instead of his head. "I am a servant, Toy?" If Tuon's tone had been cool before, now it was deep winter ice. She barely raised her voice, but it was hard as ice, too. Her expression would have made a hanging judge look giddy. "A thieving servant?" The book slid from her lap as she stood and bent to snatch up the lidded white chamber pot.

"ə feɪθləs sɝvənt?"

"A faithless servant?"

"wi wɪl nid ðæt," sɪlutʃə sɛd dɪfɝɛntʃəli, slɪpɪŋ ðə bʌlbəs pɑɾ aʊɾ ə tuɑnz hænz.

"We will need that," Selucia said deferentially, slipping the bulbous pot out of Tuon's hands.

sɛɾɪŋ ɪt kɛɹfəli tə wʌn saɪd, ʃi kɹaʊtʃt ət tuɑnz fiɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ɹɛɾi tə hɝl hɝsɛlf ət mæt, læfəbəl əz ðət wɑz. ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ mʌtʃ sim læfəbəl ɹaɪt ðɛn.

Setting it carefully to one side, she crouched at Tuon's feet almost as if ready to hurl herself at Mat, laughable as that was. Though nothing much seemed laughable right then.

mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɹitʃt ʌp tə wʌn ə ðə ɹeɪld ʃɛlvz əbʌv əɹ hɛɾ ən hændəd tuɑn ənʌðɝ kʌp. "wi hæv plɛnti ʌv ðiz," ʃi mɝmɝd.

Mistress Anan reached up to one of the railed shelves above her head and handed Tuon another cup. "We have plenty of these," she murmured.

mæt ʃɑɾ əɹ ən ɪndɪɡnən lʊk, bʌɾ əɹ heɪzəl aɪz twɪŋkəld wɪð əmjuzmənt. əmjuzmənt! ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðoʊz tu!

Mat shot her an indignant look, but her hazel eyes twinkled with amusement. Amusement! She was supposed to be guarding those two!

ə fɪs θʌmpt ɑn ðə dɔɹ. "du jə nid hɛlp ɪn ðɛɹ?" hɑɹnən kɔld ənsɝteɪnli. mæt wʌndɝd wɪtʃ ə ðɛm i wɑz æskɪŋ. "wi hæv ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛl ɪn hænd," sɛɾəl kɔl bæk, kɑmli pʊʃɪŋ əɹ niɾəl θɹu ðə fæbɹɪk stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn əɹ hup. jə wʊɾə θɔt ðət niɾəlwɝk wɑz ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ. "ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt jəɹ wɝk. doʊn dɔɾəl." ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ ɛbu dɑɹi, bʌt ʃi sɝɾənli hæd soʊkt ʌp ɛbu dɑɹi weɪz. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, buts θʌmp bæk daʊn ðə stɛps aʊtsaɪd. ɪt sim hɑɹnən hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, əz wɛl. tuɑn tɝn ðə nu kʌp ɪn əɹ hænz əz ðoʊ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə flaʊɝz peɪntəɾ ɑn ɪt, ən əɹ lɪps kwɝkt ɪn ə smaɪl soʊ smɔl ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs maɪɾ əv bɪn mæts ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən pɹɪɾi wən ʃi smaɪld, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz smaɪlz ðət sɛd ʃi nu θɪŋz i dɪd nɑt. hi wɑz gɑnə bɹeɪk aʊɾ ɪn haɪvz ɪf ʃi kɛp duɪŋ ðæt. "aɪ wɪl nɑt bi noʊn əz ə sɝvənt, tɔɪ." "maɪ neɪm ɪz mæt, nɑt . . . ðəɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋ," hi sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ tə hɪz fiɾ ən kɔʃəsli tɛstɪŋ ɪz hɪp. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ɪɾ ætʃt noʊ wɝs æftɝ smækɪŋ ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz.

A fist thumped on the door. "Do you need help in there?" Harnan called uncertainly. Mat wondered which of them he was asking. "We have everything well in hand," Setalle called back, calmly pushing her needle through the fabric stretched on her hoop. You would have thought that needlework was the most important thing. "Go on about your work. Don't dawdle." The woman was not Ebou Dari, but she certainly had soaked up Ebou Dari ways. After a moment, boots thumped back down the steps outside. It seemed Harnan had been too long in Ebou Dar, as well. Tuon turned the new cup in her hands as though examining the flowers painted on it, and her lips quirked in a smile so small it almost might have been Mat's imagination. She was more than pretty when she smiled, but it was one of those smiles that said she knew things he did not. He was going to break out in hives if she kept doing that. "I will not be known as a servant, Toy." "My name is Mat, not . . . that other thing," he said, climbing to his feet and cautiously testing his hip. To his surprise, it ached no worse after smacking the floorboards.

tuɑn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ ən hɛftəd ðə kʌp ɪn wʌn hænd. "aɪ kəd hɑɹdli tɛl ðə ʃoʊfoʊk aɪd kɪdnæp ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz," hi sɛɾ ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. "ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn, pɛzənt!" sɪlutʃə sɛd kɹɪspli. "ʃi ɪz ʌndɝ ðə veɪl!" veɪl? tuɑn hæd wɔɹn ə veɪl ɪn ðə pæləs, bʌt nɑt sɪns.

Tuon arched an eyebrow and hefted the cup in one hand. "I could hardly tell the showfolk I'd kidnapped the Daughter of the Nine Moons," he said in exasperation. "The High Lady Tuon, peasant!" Selucia said crisply. "She is under the veil!" Veil? Tuon had worn a veil in the palace, but not since.

ðə taɪni wʊmən dʒɛstʃɝd ɡɹeɪʃəsli, ə kwin ɡɹæntɪŋ laɪsəns. "ɪɾ ɪz ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹt, sɪlutʃə. hiz ɪɡnɝənt, jɛt. wi mʌst ɛdʒəkeɪt hɪm. bʌt jəl tʃeɪnʒ ðɪs stɔɹi, tɔɪ. əl nɑt bi ə sɝvənt."

The tiny woman gestured graciously, a queen granting license. "It is of no import, Selucia. He is ignorant, yet. We must educate him. But you will change this story, Toy. I will not be a servant."

"ɪts tu leɪt tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ," mæt sɛd, kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðət kʌp. hɝ hænz lʊk fɹeɪl, wɪð ðoʊz lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz kʌt ʃɔɹt, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd haʊ kwɪk ðeɪ wɝ. "noʊbɑdiz æskɪŋ jə tə bi ə sɝvənt." lukə ən ɪz waɪf nu ðə tʃɹuθ, bʌt ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm ɹizən tə ɡɪv ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls waɪ tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə wɝ kɛp kənfaɪn tə ðɪs wæɡən ən ɡɑɹɾəd. ðə pɝfək səluʃən hæd bɪn ə pɛɹ ə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝlz, əbaʊt tə bi dɪsmɪs fəɹ θɛft, hu hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ðɛɹ mɪstʃɹəsəz flaɪt wɪð əɹ lʌvɝ. ɪt sim pɝfək tə mæt, ɛniweɪ. tə ðə ʃoʊfoʊk, ɪɾ oʊnli æɾəd tə ðə ɹoʊmæns. hi hæd θɔɾ ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz gɑnə swɑloʊ hɝ tʌŋ waɪl i wɑz ɪkspleɪnɪŋ tə lukə. meɪbi ʃi hæd noʊn haʊ tuɑn wəd teɪk ɪt. laɪt, hi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ðə daɪs wəd stɑp. haʊ kəɾ ə mæn θɪŋk wɪð ðəɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd? "aɪ kʊdn liv jə bɪhaɪn tə ɹeɪz ən əlɑɹm," hi wɛn ɑn peɪʃənli. ðət wɑz tʃɹu, əz fɑɹ əz ɪt wɛnt. "aɪ noʊ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən əz ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə ju." hi θɔɾ əbaʊt seɪɪŋ i hæd bɪn bæbəlɪŋ fɹəm nɝvz wən i sɛd ʃi wɑz ɪz waɪf - ʃi mʌs θɪŋk ɪm ə kəmplit lubi! - bʌɾ ɪt sim bɛs nɑt tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn. ɪf ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə lɛt ðə mæɾɝ laɪ, ɔl ðə bɛɾɝ. "aɪ noʊ ʃiz ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl jə ðɪs, bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs noʊ wʌnz gɑnə hɝt ju. wɝ nɑɾ æftɝ ɹænsəm, dʒʌst ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ wɪð əɹ hɛdz stɪl ətætʃt. əz sun əz aɪ kən fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə sɛn jə hoʊm seɪf ən saʊnd, aɪ wɪl. aɪ pɹɑməs.

"It's too late to change anything," Mat said, keeping an eye on that cup. Her hands looked frail, with those long fingernails cut short, but he remembered how quick they were. "Nobody's asking you to be a servant." Luca and his wife knew the truth, but there had to be some reason to give everyone else why Tuon and Selucia were kept confined to this wagon and guarded. The perfect solution had been a pair of serving girls, about to be dismissed for theft, who had intended to betray their mistress's flight with her lover. It seemed perfect to Mat, anyway. To the showfolk, it only added to the romance. He had thought Egeanin was going to swallow her tongue while he was explaining to Luca. Maybe she had known how Tuon would take it. Light, he almost wished the dice would stop. How could a man think with that in his head? "I couldn't leave you behind to raise an alarm," he went on patiently. That was true, as far as it went. "I know Mistress Anan has explained it to you." He thought about saying he had been babbling from nerves when he said she was his wife - she must think him a complete looby! - but it seemed best not to bring it up again. If she was willing to let the matter lie, all the better. "I know she's already told you this, but I promise no one's going to hurt you. We're not after ransom, just getting away with our heads still attached. As soon as I can figure out how to send you home safe and sound, I will. I promise.

əl meɪk jə əz kʌmftəɹbəl əz aɪ kən əntɪl ðɛn. jəl dʒʌst əv tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ði ʌðɝ." tuɑnz bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz kɹækəld, hit laɪtnɪŋ ɪn ə naɪt skaɪ, bʌt ʃi sɛd, "ɪt simz əl si wʌt jəɹ pɹɑməsəz ɑɹ wɝθ, tɔɪ." əɾ əɹ fit, sɪlutʃə hɪs laɪk ə daʊs kæt, hɝ hɛd hæftɝnɪŋ əz ɪf tə əbdʒɛkt, bʌt tuɑnz lɛf hænd wɪɡɡəld, ən ðə bluieɪd wʊmən blʌʃt ən wɛn saɪlənt. ðə blʌd juz sʌmθɪŋ laɪk meɪɾən hæntɔk wɪð ðɛɹ ʌpɝ sɝvəns. mæt wɪʃt i ʌndɝstʊd ðə sɪɡnəlz.

I'll make you as comfortable as I can until then. You'll just have to put up with the other." Tuon's big dark eyes crackled, heat lightning in a night sky, but she said, "It seems I will see what your promises are worth, Toy." At her feet, Selucia hissed like a doused cat, her head halfturning as if to object, but Tuon's left hand wiggled, and the blueeyed woman blushed and went silent. The Blood used something like Maiden handtalk with their upper servants. Mat wished he understood the signals.

"ænsɝ mi ə kwɛstʃən, tuɑn," hi sɛd.

"Answer me a question, Tuon," he said.

hi θɔɾ i hɝd sɛɾəl mɝmɝ, "ful." sɪlutʃəz dʒɔ nɑɾɪd, ən ə deɪnʒɝəs lʊk kɪndəld ɪn tuɑnz aɪz, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz gɑnə kɔl ɪm "tɔɪ," hi wəd bi bɝn ɪf i ɡeɪv əɹ ɛni taɪɾəlz.

He thought he heard Setalle murmur, "Fool." Selucia's jaw knotted, and a dangerous look kindled in Tuon's eyes, but if she was going to call him "Toy," he would be burned if he gave her any titles.

"haʊ oʊld ɑɹ ju?" hi hæd hɝd ðət ʃi wɑz oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən hi, bʌt lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɪn ðət sæk ʌv ə dʒɹɛs, ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl.

"How old are you?" He had heard that she was only a few years younger than he, but looking at her in that sack of a dress, it seemed impossible.

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ðət deɪnʒɝəs spɑɹk bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. nɑt dʒʌs hit laɪtnɪŋ, ðɪs taɪm. hi ʃʊɾə bɪn fɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə spɑt. tuɑn θɹu bæk əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən dʒɹu hɝsɛlf tə hɝ fʊl haɪt.

To his surprise, that dangerous spark burst into flame. Not just heat lightning, this time. He should have been fried on the spot. Tuon threw back her shoulders and drew herself to her full height.

sətʃ əz ðət wɑz; hi daʊɾɪd ʃi kəd ɹitʃ faɪv fit wɪð əɹ hilz flæt haʊɛvɝ ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt. "maɪ fɔɹtinθ tʃɹu-neɪm deɪ wɪl kʌm ɪn faɪv mʌnθs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm koʊld. ɪn fækt, ɪt cʊɾə hiɾəd ðə wæɡən bɛɾɝ ðən ðə stoʊv. hi fɛlt ə moʊmən ə hoʊp, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt fɪnɪʃt.

Such as that was; he doubted she could reach five feet with her heels flat however she stretched. "My fourteenth true-name day will come in five months," she said in a voice that was far from cold. In fact, it could have heated the wagon better than the stove. He felt a moment of hope, but she was not finished.

"noʊ; jə kip jəɹ bɝθ neɪmz hɪɹ, doʊn ju. ðət wɪl bi maɪ twɛntiəθ neɪmɪŋ deɪ. ɑɹ jə sæɾəsfaɪd, tɔɪ? dɪd jə fɪɹ jə hæd stoʊlən ə . . . tʃaɪld?" ʃi ɔlmoʊs hɪs ðə læst wɝd.

"No; you keep your birth names here, don't you. That will be my twentieth naming day. Are you satisfied, Toy? Did you fear you had stolen a . . . child?" She almost hissed the last word.

mæt weɪvd ɪz hænz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, fɹæntəkəli dɪsmɪsɪŋ ðə sədʒɛstʃən. ə wʊmən stɑɹɾəd hɪsɪŋ əɾ ɪm laɪk ə kɛɾəl, ə mæn wɪð ɛni bɹeɪnz faʊn ə weɪ tə kul əɹ daʊn fæst. ʃi wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə kʌp soʊ taɪtli ðət tɛndənz stʊɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə tʃɹaɪ hɪz hɪp wɪð ənʌðɝ fɔl tə ðə flɔɹ. kʌm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hɑɹd ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə hɪɾ ɪm ðə fɝs taɪm. hɝ hænz wɝ vɛɹi fæst. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə noʊ, ðæts ɔl," hi sɛd kwɪkli. "aɪ wɑz kjʊɹiəs, meɪkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən. aɪm oʊnli ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ maɪsɛlf." twɛnti. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ hoʊpɪŋ ʃi wɑz tu jʌŋ tə mɛɹi fəɹ ənʌðɝ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ jɪɹz. ɛniθɪŋ ðət keɪm bɪtwin ɪm ən ɪz wɛɾɪŋ deɪ wʊɾə bɪn wɛlkəm.

Mat waved his hands in front of him, frantically dismissing the suggestion. A woman started hissing at him like a kettle, a man with any brains found a way to cool her down fast. She was gripping the cup so tightly that tendons stood out on the back of her hand, and he did not want to try his hip with another fall to the floor. Come to think on it, he was not sure how hard she had tried to hit him the first time. Her hands were very fast. "I just wanted to know, that's all," he said quickly. "I was curious, making conversation. I'm only a little older myself." Twenty. So much for hoping she was too young to marry for another three or four years. Anything that came between him and his wedding day would have been welcome.

tuɑn stʌɾid ɪm səspɪʃəsli wɪð əɹ hɛd tɪltəd, ðən tɔs ðə kʌp ɑntu ðə bɛd bɪsaɪd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ən siɾəd hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə stul əɡɛn, teɪkɪŋ əz mʌtʃ kɛɹ əbaʊɾ ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ vəlumənəs wʊlən skɝts əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪlɔŋ tə ə sɪlk ɡaʊn. bʌt ʃi kəntɪnjud tə ɪɡzæmɪn ɪm θɹu hɝ lɔŋ aɪlæʃɪz. "wɛɹ ɪz jəɹ ɹɪŋ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

Tuon studied him suspiciously with her head tilted, then tossed the cup onto the bed beside Mistress Anan and seated herself on the stool again, taking as much care about arranging her voluminous woolen skirts as if they had belonged to a silk gown. But she continued to examine him through her long eyelashes. "Where is your ring?" she demanded.

ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hi θʌm ðə fɪŋɡɝ ɑn ɪz lɛf hænd wɛɹ ðə lɔŋ ɹɪŋ juʒəwəli leɪ. "aɪ doʊnt wɛɹ ɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm." nɑt wən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs nu hi wɔɹ ɪt. ðə θɪŋ wʊɾə stʊɾ aʊt, wɪð ɪz ɹʌf laɪəbaʊts ɡɑɹb, ɪn ɛni keɪs. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ivən ɪz sɪɡnɪt, ɛniweɪ, dʒʌst ə kɑɹvɝz tʃɹaɪ-pis. stʃɹeɪnʒ, haʊ hɪz hæn fɛl noʊɾɪsəbli laɪɾɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. tu laɪt. stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ʃi ɹɪmɑɹkt ɑn ɪt, tu. bʌt ðɛn, waɪ nɑt? laɪt, ðoʊz daɪs hæɾ ɪm ʃaɪɪŋ ət ʃædoʊz ən dʒʌmpɪŋ ət saɪz. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌs hɝ, ə dɪskʌmfɝɾɪŋ θɔt.

Unconsciously, he thumbed the finger on his left hand where the long ring usually lay. "I don't wear it all the time." Not when everybody in the Tarasin Palace knew he wore it. The thing would have stood out, with his rough layabout's garb, in any case. It was not even his signet, anyway, just a carver's try-piece. Strange, how his hand felt noticeably lighter without it. Too light. Strange that she remarked on it, too. But then, why not? Light, those dice had him shying at shadows and jumping at sighs. Or maybe it was just her, a discomforting thought.

hi muv tə sɪɾ ɑn ði ənɑkjəpaɪd bɛd, bʌt sɪlutʃə swʌŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp ɑntu ɪt soʊ kwɪkli ɛni ʌv ði ækɹəbæts maɪɾ əv bɪn dʒɛləs, ən stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt wɪð əɹ hɛd pɹɑpt ɑn əɹ hænd.

He moved to sit on the unoccupied bed, but Selucia swung herself up onto it so quickly any of the acrobats might have been jealous, and stretched out with her head propped on her hand.

ðət pʊʃt əɹ skɑɹf əskju fəɹ ə moʊmənt, bʌt ʃi hɝidli stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪt, ɔl ðə waɪl stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm pɹaʊɾ ən koʊld əz ə kwin. hi lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝ bɛd, ən mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən sɛt daʊn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɑstənteɪʃəsli smuð əɹ skɝts, meɪkɪŋ ɪt klɪɹ ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ʃɛɹ ən ɪntʃ. bɝn hɝ, ʃi wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ tuɑn fɹəm hɪm! wɪmən ɔlweɪz sim tə klʌb təɡɛðɝ soʊ ə mæn nɛvɝ hæɾ ə fɛɹ tʃæns. wɛl, hi hæd mænədʒ tə kip ɛdʒiənɪn fɹəm teɪkɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ soʊ fɑɹ, ən i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bi bʊlid baɪ sɛɾəl ɑnən əɹ ə boʊsəmi leɪɾiz meɪɾ əɹ ðə haɪ ən maɪɾi haɪ leɪɾi dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn blʌɾi munz! oʊnli, hi kəd hɑɹdli ɡoʊ ʃʌvɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛm aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ tə faɪn ə pleɪs tə sɪt.

That pushed her scarf askew for a moment, but she hurriedly straightened it, all the while staring at him proud and cold as a queen. He looked at the other bed, and Mistress Anan set down her embroidery long enough to ostentatiously smooth her skirts, making it clear she did not intend to share an inch. Burn her, she was behaving as though she were guarding Tuon from him! Women always seemed to club together so a man never had a fair chance. Well, he had managed to keep Egeanin from taking charge so far, and he was not about to be bullied by Setalle Anan or a bosomy lady's maid or the high and mighty High Lady Daughter of the Nine bloody Moons! Only, he could hardly go shoving one of them out of the way to find a place to sit.

linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə dʒɹɔɝd kæbənəɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛd mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɑz siɾəd ɑn, hi tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt tə seɪ. hi nɛvɝ hæd tʃɹʌbəl θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt tə seɪ tə wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪz bɹeɪn sim dɛfən baɪ ðə saʊn ə ðoʊz daɪs. ɔl θɹi wɪmən ɡeɪv ɪm dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ lʊks - hi kəɾ ɔl bʌt hɪɹ wʌn ə ðɛm tɛlɪŋ ɪm nɑt tə slaʊtʃ! - soʊ hi smaɪld. moʊst wɪmən θɔɾ ɪz bɛst smaɪl vɛɹi wɪnɪŋ.

Leaning against a drawered cabinet at the foot of the bed Mistress Anan was seated on, he tried to think of what to say. He never had trouble thinking of what to say to women, but his brain seemed deafened by the sound of those dice. All three women gave him disapproving looks - he could all but hear one of them telling him not to slouch! - so he smiled. Most women thought his best smile very winning.

tuɑn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ ðət dɪd nɑt saʊnd wʌn oʊvɝ ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst. "du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɔkwɪŋz feɪs, tɔɪ?" mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən sɪlutʃə sæɾ ʌp ɑn ðə bɛd fɹaʊnɪŋ. ət hɪm. waɪ wəd ʃi fɹaʊn ət hɪm? tuɑn dʒʌs kəntɪnjud tə lʊk ət hɪm, hænz foʊldəɾ ɪn əɹ læp, əz kul ən kəlɛktəɾ əz ə wɪzdəm ət sʌndeɪ.

Tuon let out a long breath that did not sound won over in the slightest. "Do you remember Hawkwing's face, Toy?" Mistress Anan blinked in surprise, and Selucia sat up on the bed frowning. At him. Why would she frown at him? Tuon just continued to look at him, hands folded in her lap, as cool and collected as a Wisdom at Sunday.

mæts smaɪl fɛl fɹoʊzən. laɪt, wʌd ʃi noʊ? haʊ kəd ʃi noʊ ɛniθɪŋ? hi leɪ bɪniθ ðə bɝnɪŋ sʌn, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz saɪd wɪð boʊθ hænz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðə læst ə laɪf fɹəm likɪŋ aʊɾ ən wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni ɹizən tə hoʊld ɑn. eɪdʃɑɝ wɑz fɪnɪʃt, æftɝ ðɪs deɪz wɝk. ə ʃædoʊ blɑɾɪd ðə sʌn fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ən ðən ə tɔl mæn ɪn ɑɹmɝ kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd hɪm, hɛlmət tʌkt ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm, dɑɹk dip-sɛɾ aɪz fɹeɪmɪŋ ə hʊk noʊz. "ju fɔt wɛl əɡɛns mi tədeɪ, kjuln, ən mɛni deɪz pæst," ðət mɛmɝəbəl vɔɪs sɛd. "wɪl jə lɪv wɪð mi ɪn pis?" wɪð ɪz læs bɹɛθ, hi læft ɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz feɪs. hi heɪɾəd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ daɪɪŋ. ə dʌzən ʌðɝ ɪnkaʊntɝz skɪɾɝd θɹu hɪz maɪnd, tu, eɪntʃən mɛmɹiz ðət wɝ hɪz, naʊ. ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ hæd bɪn ə dɪfəkəl mæn tə ɡɛɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ivən bɪfɔɹ ðə wɔɹz stɑɹɾəd.

Mat's smile felt frozen. Light, what did she know? How could she know anything? He lay beneath the burning sun, holding his side with both hands, trying to keep the last of life from leaking out and wondering whether there was any reason to hold on. Aideshar was finished, after this day's work. A shadow blotted the sun for an instant, and then a tall man in armor crouched beside him, helmet tucked under his arm, dark deep-set eyes framing a hooked nose. "You fought well against me today, Culain, and many days past," that memorable voice said. "Will you live with me in peace?" With his last breath, he laughed in Artur Hawkwing's face. He hated to remember dying. A dozen other encounters skittered through his mind, too, ancient memories that were his, now. Artur Paendrag had been a difficult man to get along with even before the wars started.

dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi tʊk kɛɹ tʃuzɪŋ ɪz wɝdz. ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm tə ɡoʊ spaʊɾɪŋ ði oʊl tʌŋ. "ʌv kɔɹs aɪ doʊnt!" hi laɪd. ə mæn u kəd nɑt laɪ kənvɪnsɪŋli ɡɑt ʃɔɹt ʃɹɪft fɹəm wɪmən. "laɪt, hɔkwɪŋ daɪɾ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ! wʌt kaɪndə kwɛstʃən ɪz ðæt?" hɝ maʊθ oʊpən sloʊli, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi mɛn tə ænsɝ kwɛstʃən wɪð kwɛstʃən. "ə fulɪʃ wʌn, tɔɪ," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd faɪnəli, ɪnstɛd. "aɪ kæn seɪ waɪ ɪt pɑpt ɪndə maɪ hɛd." ðə stɪfnəs ɪn mæts ʃoʊldɝz ɹɪlækst, ə lɪɾəl. ʌv kɔɹs. hi wɑz tɑvɝən. pipəl dɪd θɪŋz ən sɛd θɪŋz ɝaʊn ɪm ðeɪ nɛvɝ wəɾ ɛlswɛɹ. nɑnsɛns kwɑləfaɪd. stɪl, ə θɪŋ laɪk ðət kəd bɪkʌm ənkʌmftəɹbəl wən ɪt hɪt tu kloʊs tə hoʊm. "maɪ neɪm ɪz mæt. mæt kɔθən." hi maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv spoʊkən. "aɪ kænɑt seɪ wʌɾ əl də æftɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ɛbu dɑɹ, tɔɪ. aɪ hæv nɑt dɪsaɪɾɪd. aɪ meɪ hæv jə meɪd dækoʊvə. jə ɑɹ nɑt pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf fəɹ ə kʌbɛɹɝ, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt pliz mi tə hæv jə fəɹ wʌn. stɪl, juv ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd sɝɾən pɹɑməsəz tə mi, soʊ ɪt plizɪz mi naʊ tə pɹɑməs, əz wɛl. soʊ lɔŋ əz jə kip jəɹ pɹɑməsəz, əl niðɝ ɪskeɪp nɔɹ bɪtʃɹeɪ jə ɪn ɛni weɪ, nɔɹ wɪl aɪ kɑz dɪsɛnʃən əmʌŋ jəɹ fɑloʊɝz. aɪ bɪliv ðət kʌvɝz ɛvɹiθɪŋ nɛsəsɛɹi." ðɪs taɪm, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, ən sɪlutʃə meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, bʌt tuɑn əpɪɹd nɑt tə noʊɾəs iðɝ wʊmən. ʃi dʒʌs lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɪkspɛktənli, weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə ɹɪspɑns. hi meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, tu. nɑɾ ə wɪmpɝ, dʒʌst ə saʊnd. tuɑnz feɪs wɑz əz smuð əz ə stɝn mæsk ə dɑɹk ɡlæs. hɝ kɑm wɑz mædnəs, bʌt ðɪs meɪd ɡɪbɝɪŋ lʊk seɪn! ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi ɪnseɪn tə θɪŋk i wəd bɪliv ðəɾ ɔfɝ.

Drawing a deep breath, he took care choosing his words. This was no time to go spouting the Old Tongue. "Of course I don't!" he lied. A man who could not lie convincingly got short shrift from women. "Light, Hawkwing died a thousand years ago! What kind of question is that?" Her mouth opened slowly, and for a moment he was sure she meant to answer question with question. "A foolish one, Toy," she replied finally, instead. "I can't say why it popped into my head." The stiffness in Mat's shoulders relaxed, a little. Of course. He was ta'veren. People did things and said things around him they never would elsewhere. Nonsense qualified. Still, a thing like that could become uncomfortable when it hit too close to home. "My name is Mat. Mat Cauthon." He might as well not have spoken. "I cannot say what I will do after returning to Ebou Dar, Toy. I have not decided. I may have you made da'covah. You are not pretty enough for a cupbearer, but it might please me to have you for one. Still, you have represented certain promises to me, so it pleases me now to promise, as well. So long as you keep your promises, I will neither escape nor betray you in any way, nor will I cause dissension among your followers. I believe that covers everything necessary." This time, Mistress Anan gaped at her, and Selucia made a sound in her throat, but Tuon appeared not to notice either woman. She just looked at him expectantly, waiting on a response. He made a sound in his throat, too. Not a whimper, just a sound. Tuon's face was as smooth as a stern mask of dark glass. Her calm was madness, but this made gibbering look sane! She would have to be insane to think he would believe that offer.

ɪksɛpt, hi θɔt ʃi dɪd min ɪt. ðæt, əɹ ʃi wɑz ə bɛɾɝ laɪɝ ðən i ɛvɝ hoʊp tə bi. əɡɛn i hæd ðət kwizi sɛns ðət ʃi nu mɔɹ ðən i dɪd. ɹɪdɪkjələs, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðəɹ ɪt wɑz. hi swɑloʊɾ ə lʌmp ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. ə hɑɹd lʌmp.

Except, he thought she did mean it. That, or she was a better liar than he ever hoped to be. Again he had that queasy sense that she knew more than he did. Ridiculous, of course, but there it was. He swallowed a lump in his throat. A hard lump.

"wɛl, ðət dʌz ɔl ɹaɪt fəɹ ju," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə baɪ taɪm, "bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊt sɪlutʃə?" taɪm fəɹ wʌt? hi kəd nɑt θɪŋk wɪð ðoʊz daɪs paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz skʌl.

"Well, that does all right for you," he said, trying to buy time, "but what about Selucia?" Time for what? He could not think with those dice pounding in his skull.

"sɪlutʃə fɑloʊz maɪ wɪʃɪz, tɔɪ," tuɑn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən hɝsɛlf stʃɹeɪɾənd ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ðoʊ ɪndɪɡnən ðəɾ i hæd daʊɾɪd ðæt. fəɹ ə leɪɾiz meɪd, ʃi kəd lʊk fɪɹs wən ʃi tʃɹaɪd.

"Selucia follows my wishes, Toy," Tuon said impatiently. The blue-eyed woman herself straightened and stared at him as though indignant that he had doubted that. For a lady's maid, she could look fierce when she tried.

mæt dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ əɹ du. wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi spæɾ ɑn ɪz pɑm ən ɔfɝɾ ɪz hæn əz ɪf silɪŋ ə bɑɹɡən ɑn ə hɔɹs.

Mat did not know what to say or do. Without thinking, he spat on his palm and offered his hand as if sealing a bargain on a horse.

"jɔɹ kʌstəmz ɑɹ . . . ɝθi," tuɑn sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi spæɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn pɑm ən klæspt ɪz hænd. " 'ðʌs ɪz əɹ tʃɹiɾi ɹɪɾən; ðʌs ɪz əɡɹimən meɪd.' wʌt dʌz ðət ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn jəɹ spɪɹ min, tɔɪ?"

"Your customs are . . . earthy," Tuon said in a dry voice, but she spat on her own palm and clasped his hand. " 'Thus is our treaty written; thus is agreement made.' What does that writing on your spear mean, Toy?"

hi dɪd wɪmpɝ ðɪs taɪm, ən nɑt kəz ʃi hæd ɹɛd ði oʊl tʌŋ ɪnskɹɪpʃən ɑn ɪz æʃhændʒɹeɪ. ə blʌɾi stoʊn wəɾ əv wɪmpɝd. ðə daɪs hæd stɑpt əz sun əz i tʌtʃt əɹ hænd. laɪt, wʌt hæd hæpənd?

He did whimper this time, and not because she had read the Old Tongue inscription on his ashandarei. A bloody stone would have whimpered. The dice had stopped as soon as he touched her hand. Light, what had happened?

nʌkəlz ɹæpt ɑn ðə dɔɹ, ən i wɑz soʊ ɑn ɛdʒ ðəɾ i muvd wɪθaʊt θɔt, spɪnɪŋ, ə naɪf kʌmɪŋ ɪndə iðɝ hæn ɹɛɾi tə θɹoʊ ət wʌtɛvɝ keɪm ɪn. "steɪ bɪhaɪn mi," hi snæpt. ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən tɑm stʌk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn. ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk wɑz ʌp, ən mæt ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz ɹeɪnɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. bɪtwin tuɑn ən ðə daɪs, hi hæd mɪs ðə saʊn ə ɹeɪn hɪɾɪŋ ðə wæɡənz ɹuf. "aɪ tʃɹʌst aɪm nɑɾ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ?" tɑm sɛd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz.

Knuckles rapped on the door, and he was so on edge that he moved without thought, spinning, a knife coming into either hand ready to throw at whatever came in. "Stay behind me," he snapped. The door opened, and Thom stuck his head in. The hood of his cloak was up, and Mat realized it was raining outside. Between Tuon and the dice, he had missed the sound of rain hitting the wagon's roof. "I trust I'm not interrupting anything?" Thom said, knuckling his long white mustaches.

mæts feɪs hiɾəd. sɛɾəl hæd fɹoʊzən wɪð əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi niɾəl tʃɹeɪlɪŋ blu θɹɛd daʊn tə hɝ wɝk, ən əɹ aɪbɹaʊz sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klaɪm oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd. tɛnst ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ði ʌðɝ bɛd, sɪlutʃə wɑtʃt ɪm slɪp ðə naɪvz bæk ʌp ɪz slivz wɪð kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɪntʃɹəst. hi wəd nɑɾ əv θɔt ʃi wɑz ðə sɔɹt tə laɪk deɪnʒɝəs mɛn. ðət kaɪndə wʊmən wɑz wɝθ əvɔɪɾɪŋ; ðeɪ tɛndəd tə faɪnd weɪz tə meɪk ə mæn nid tə bi deɪnʒɝəs. hi dɪd nɑt ɡlæns bæk ət tuɑn. ʃi wɑz pɹɑbli stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i hæd bɪn keɪpɝɪŋ laɪk lukə. dʒʌs kəz i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɡɛt mɛɹid dɪd nɑt min i wɑntəɾ ɪz fjutʃɝ waɪf tə θɪŋk ɪm ə ful.

Mat's face heated. Setalle had frozen with her embroidery needle trailing blue thread down to her work, and her eyebrows seemed to be trying to climb over the top of her head. Tensed on the edge of the other bed, Selucia watched him slip the knives back up his sleeves with considerable interest. He would not have thought she was the sort to like dangerous men. That kind of woman was worth avoiding; they tended to find ways to make a man need to be dangerous. He did not glance back at Tuon. She was probably staring at him as if he had been capering like Luca. Just because he did not want to get married did not mean he wanted his future wife to think him a fool.

"wʌt dɪd jə faɪn aʊt, tɑm?" hi æsk bɹʌskli. sʌmθɪŋ hæd hæpənd, əɹ ðə daɪs wəd nɑɾ əv stɑpt. ə θɔt keɪm ðət meɪɾ ɪz hɛɹ wɑnə stæn ɑn ɛnd. ðɪs wɑz ðə sɛkən taɪm ðeɪ hæd stɑpt ɪn tuɑnz pɹɛzəns. ðə θɝd, kaʊntɪŋ ðə ɡeɪt liɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ. θɹi blʌɾi taɪmz, ən ɔl taɪd tə hɝ.

"What did you find out, Thom?" he asked brusquely. Something had happened, or the dice would not have stopped. A thought came that made his hair want to stand on end. This was the second time they had stopped in Tuon's presence. The third, counting the gate leading out of Ebou Dar. Three bloody times, and all tied to her.

lɪmpɪŋ slaɪtli, ðə waɪt-hɛɹd mæn keɪm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɪn, pʊʃɪŋ bæk ɪz hʊd, ən pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɪm. hɪz lɪmp keɪm fɹəm ən oʊld ɪnʒɝi, nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi. tɔl ən lin ən lɛðɝi, wɪð ʃɑɹp blu aɪz ən snoʊi mʌstæʃɪz ðət hʌŋ bɪloʊ hɪz tʃɪn, ɪt simd i wəd dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt, bʌɾ i hæd pɹæktəs ət haɪɾɪŋ ɪn pleɪn saɪt, ən ɪz dɑɹk bɹɑnz koʊɾ ən bɹaʊn wʊl kloʊk wɝ suɾəbəl fəɹ ə mæn wɪð ə lɪɾəl kɔɪn tə spɛn bʌt nɑt tu mʌtʃ. "ðə stʃɹits ɑɹ fʊl ə ɹumɝz əbaʊt hɝ," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd tuɑn, "bʌt nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ. aɪ bɑt dʒɹɪŋks fəɹ ə fju sintʃæn ɔfəsɝz, ən ðeɪ sim tə bɪliv ʃiz snʌɡ ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs əɹ ɔf ɑn ən ɪnspɛkʃən tʃɹɪp. aɪ dɪdn sɛns ɛni dɪsəmbəlɪŋ, mæt. ðeɪ dɪdnt noʊ."

Limping slightly, the white-haired man came the rest of the way in, pushing back his hood, and pulled the door shut behind him. His limp came from an old injury, not trouble in the city. Tall and lean and leathery, with sharp blue eyes and snowy mustaches that hung below his chin, it seemed he would draw attention wherever he went, but he had practice at hiding in plain sight, and his dark bronze coat and brown wool cloak were suitable for a man with a little coin to spend but not too much. "The streets are full of rumors about her," he said, nodding toward Tuon, "but nothing about her disappearing. I bought drinks for a few Seanchan officers, and they seem to believe she's snug in the Tarasin Palace or off on an inspection trip. I didn't sense any dissembling, Mat. They didn't know."

"dɪd jə ɪkspɛk pʌblɪk ənaʊnsməns, tɔɪ?" tuɑn sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "æz ɪɾ ɪz, sjuɹɔθ meɪ bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ teɪkɪŋ əɹ oʊn laɪf fəɹ ðə ʃeɪm. dʒju ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə spɹɛd sətʃ ən ɪl oʊmən fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn əbaʊt fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə si ɑn tɑp ə ðæt?" soʊ ɛdʒiənɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ɪt stɪl simd ɪmpɑsəbəl.

"Did you expect public announcements, Toy?" Tuon said incredulously. "As it is, Suroth may be considering taking her own life for the shame. Do you expect her to spread such an ill omen for the Return about for everyone to see on top of that?" So Egeanin had been right. It still seemed impossible.

ən ɪt dɪd nɑt sim əɾ ɔl ɪmpɔɹɾənt kəmpɛɹd tə ðə daɪs stɑpɪŋ. wʌt hæd hæpənd'? hi hæd ʃeɪkən hænz wɪð tuɑn, ðət wɑz ɔl. ʃeɪkən hænz ən meɪɾ ə bɑɹɡən. hi mɛn tə kip ɪz saɪd, bʌt wʌt hæd ðə daɪs toʊl hɪm? ðət ʃi wəd kip hɝz? əɹ ðət ʃi wəd nɑt? fəɹ ɔl i nu, sintʃæn noʊbəlwɪmən wɝ ɪn ðə hæbəɾ ə mɛɹiɪŋ - wʌt wɑz ɪt ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi wɑz gɑnə meɪk hɪm? - ə kʌbɛɹɝ - meɪbi ðeɪ mɛɹid kʌbɛɹɝz ɔl ðə taɪm. "ðɛɹz mɔɹ, mæt," tɑm sɛd, aɪɪŋ tuɑn θɔtfəli, ən wɪð ə hɪn ə sɝpɹaɪz. ɪt keɪm tə mæt ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ oʊvɝli kənsɝn ðət sjuɹɔθ maɪt kɪl hɝsɛlf. meɪbi ʃi wɑz əz tʌf əz doʊmən θɔt. wʌt wɝ ðə blʌɾi daɪs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɛl hɪm? ðət wɑz wʌt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðən tɑm wɛn ɑn, ən mæt fɝɡɑɾ əbaʊt haʊ tʌf tuɑn maɪt bi ən ivən ðə daɪs. "taɪlɪnz dɛd. ðəɹ kipɪŋ ɪt kwaɪət fəɹ fɪɹ ə dɪstɝbənsəz, bʌt wʌn ə ðə pæləs ɡɑɹdz, ə jʌŋ lutɛnən u kʊdn hoʊld ɪz bɹændi, toʊl mi ðəɹ plænɪŋ əɹ fjunɝəl fist ən bɛslənz kɔɹəneɪʃən fəɹ ðə seɪm deɪ."

And it did not seem at all important compared to the dice stopping. What had happened'? He had shaken hands with Tuon, that was all. Shaken hands and made a bargain. He meant to keep his side, but what had the dice told him? That she would keep hers? Or that she would not? For all he knew, Seanchan noblewomen were in the habit of marrying - what was it she had said she was going to make him? - a cupbearer - maybe they married cupbearers all the time. "There's more, Mat," Thom said, eyeing Tuon thoughtfully, and with a hint of surprise. It came to Mat that she did not appear overly concerned that Suroth might kill herself. Maybe she was as tough as Domon thought. What were the bloody dice trying to tell him? That was what was important. Then Thom went on, and Mat forgot about how tough Tuon might be and even the dice. "Tylin's dead. They're keeping it quiet for fear of disturbances, but one of the Palace Guards, a young lieutenant who couldn't hold his brandy, told me they're planning her funeral feast and Beslan's coronation for the same day."

"haʊ?" mæt dɪmændəd. ʃi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən hi, bʌt nɑt ðət mʌtʃ oʊldɝ! bɛslənz kɔɹəneɪʃən.

"How?" Mat demanded. She was older than he, but not that much older! Beslan's coronation.

laɪt! haʊ wəd bɛslən koʊp wɪð ðæt, wən i heɪɾəd ðə sintʃæn? ɪt hæd bɪn ɪz plæn tə faɪɝ ðoʊz səplaɪz ɑn ðə beɪ ɹoʊd. hi wʊɾə tʃɹaɪɾ ən əpɹaɪzɪŋ ɪf mæt hæd nɑt kənvɪnst ɪm ɪt wəɾ oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt ɪn ə slɔɾɝ, ən nɑɾ ə sintʃæn.

Light! How would Beslan cope with that, when he hated the Seanchan? It had been his plan to fire those supplies on the Bay Road. He would have tried an uprising if Mat had not convinced him it would only result in a slaughter, and not of Seanchan.

tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə θʌm. faɪnəli, hi saɪd. "ʃi wɑz faʊn ɪn əɹ bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ wi lɛft, mæt, stɪl baʊn hæn ən fʊt. hɝ hɛd. . . . hɝ hɛd hæd bɪn tɔɹn ɔf."

Thom hesitated, stroking his mustaches with a thumb. Finally, he sighed. "She was found in her bedchamber the morning after we left, Mat, still bound hand and foot. Her head. . . . Her head had been torn off."

mæt dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ɪz niz hæd ɡɪvən weɪ əntɪl i faʊn hɪmsɛlf sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ wɪð ɪz hɛd bʌzɪŋ. hi kəd hɪɹ əɹ vɔɪs. jəl ɡɛt jəɹ bid kʌɾ ɔf jɛɾ ɪf jəɹ nɑt kɛɹfəl, paɪɡlɛt, ən aɪ wʊdn laɪk ðæt. sɛɾəl lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛd tə pɹɛs ə hæn əɡɛnst ɪz tʃik ɪn kəməzɝeɪʃən. "ðə wɪndfɪndɝz?" hi sɛd hɑloʊli. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə seɪ mɔɹ.

Mat did not realize his knees had given way until he found himself sitting on the floor with his head buzzing. He could hear her voice. You'll get your bead cut off yet if you're not careful, piglet, and I wouldn't like that. Setalle leaned forward on the narrow bed to press a hand against his cheek in commiseration. "The Windfinders?" he said hollowly. He did not have to say more.

"əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə wʌt ðət lutɛnən sɛd, ðə sintʃæn əv sɛɾəld ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ðə bleɪm.

"According to what that lieutenant said, the Seanchan have settled on Aes Sedai for the blame.

kəz taɪlɪn hæd swɔɹn ðə sintʃæn oʊðz. ðæts wʌt ðəl ənaʊns əɾ əɹ fjunɝəl fist." "taɪlɪn daɪz ðə seɪm naɪt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɪskeɪp, ən ðə sintʃæn bɪliv ɛɛs sədaɪ kɪl hɝ?" hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən taɪlɪn dɛd. aɪm gɑnə hæv jə fəɹ sʌpɝ, dʌklɪŋ. "ðæt dʌzn meɪk sɛns, tɑm." tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əz i kənsɪɾɝd. "ɪt kəd bi pəlɪɾəkəl, ɪn pɑɹt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðæts wʌt ðeɪ ɹɪli bɪliv, mæt. ðət lutɛnən sɛd ðəɹ ʃʊɹ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ tu hɑɹd tə stɑp əɹ ɡoʊ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ, ən ðə kwɪkɪs pæθ aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs fɹəm ðə deɪmeɪn kɛnəlz ɡoʊz noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns."

Because Tylin had sworn the Seanchan oaths. That's what they'll announce at her funeral feast." "Tylin dies the same night the Windfinders escape, and the Seanchan believe Aes Sedai killed her?" He could not imagine Tylin dead. I'm going to have you for supper, duckling. "That doesn't make sense, Thom." Thom hesitated, frowning as he considered. "It could be political, in part, but I think that's what they really believe, Mat. That lieutenant said they're sure the Windfinders were running too hard to stop or go out of their way, and the quickest path out of the palace from the damane kennels goes nowhere near Tylin's apartments."

mæt ɡɹʌntɪd. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ. ən ɪf ɪt wɝ, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld i kəd də əbaʊɾ ɪt.

Mat grunted. He was sure it was not so. And if it were, there was nothing in the world he could do about it.

"ðə mɑɹ æθdəmeɪn hæd ɹizən tə mɝɾɝ taɪlɪn," sɪlutʃə sɛd sʌɾənli. "ðeɪ mʌs fɪɹ əɹ ɪɡzæmpəl fəɹ ʌðɝz. wʌt ɹizən hæd ðə deɪmeɪn jə spik ʌv? nʌn. ðə hæn ə dʒʌstəs ɹikwaɪɝz moʊɾɪv ən pɹuf, ivən fəɹ deɪmeɪn ən dækoʊvæl." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ɹiɾɪŋ ðə wɝdz ɔf ə peɪdʒ. ən ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət tuɑn fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ.

"The mar ath'damane had reason to murder Tylin," Selucia said suddenly. "They must fear her example for others. What reason had the damane you speak of? None. The hand of justice requires motive and proof, even for damane and da'covale." She sounded as though she were reading the words off a page. And she was looking at Tuon from the corner of her eye.

mæt lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ðə taɪni wʊmən hæd bɪn juzɪŋ əɹ hænz tə tɛl sɪlutʃə wʌt tə seɪ, ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn əɹ læp, naʊ. ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ə nutʃɹəl ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Mat looked over his shoulder, but if the tiny woman had been using her hands to tell Selucia what to say, they were resting in her lap, now. She was watching him, a neutral expression on her face.

"dɪd jə kɛɹ fəɹ taɪlɪn soʊ dipli?" ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kɔʃəs vɔɪs.

"Did you care for Tylin so deeply?" she said in a cautious voice.

"jɛs. noʊ. bɝn mi, aɪ laɪk hɝ!" tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, hi skɹʌb fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, pʊʃɪŋ ðə kæp ɔf. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ ɡlæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ə wʊmən ɪn ɪz laɪf, bʌt ðɪs . . . ! "æn aɪ lɛft əɹ taɪɾ ʌp ən ɡæɡd soʊ ʃi kʊdn ivən kɔl fəɹ hɛlp, izi pɹeɪ fəɹ ðə ɡoʊləm," hi sɛd bɪɾɝli. "ɪt wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi. doʊnt ʃeɪk jəɹ hɛd. tɑm. jə noʊ ɪɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ du." "wʌɾ ɪz ə . . . ɡoʊləm?" tuɑn æskt.

"Yes. No. Burn me, I liked her!" Turning away, he scrubbed fingers through his hair, pushing the cap off. He had never been so glad to get away from a woman in his life, but this . . . ! "And I left her tied up and gagged so she couldn't even call for help, easy prey for the gholam," he said bitterly. "It was looking for me. Don't shake your head. Thom. You know it as well as I do." "What is a . . . gholam?" Tuon asked.

"ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, maɪ leɪɾi," tɑm sɛd. hi fɹaʊnd wɝidli. hi dɪd nɑt teɪk izəli tə wɝi, bʌɾ ɛnibəɾi ɪksɛpt ə ful wəd wɝi əbaʊɾ ə ɡoʊləm. "ɪt lʊks laɪk ə mæn, bʌɾ ɪt kən slɪp θɹu ə maʊshoʊl, əɹ ʌndɝ ə dɔɹ, ən ɪts stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə. . . ." hi hæɹəmf θɹu hɪz mʌstæʃɪz.

"Shadowspawn, my Lady," Thom said. He frowned worriedly. He did not take easily to worry, but anybody except a fool would worry about a gholam. "It looks like a man, but it can slip through a mousehole, or under a door, and it's strong enough to. . . ." He harrumphed through his mustaches.

"wɛl, ɪnʌf ə ðæt. mæt, ʃi cʊɾə hæɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡɑɹdz ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ɪt wʊdn əv stɑp ðət θɪŋ." ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv niɾəd ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡɑɹdz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt teɪkən ʌp wɪð mæt kɔθən. "ə ɡoʊləm," tuɑn mɝmɝd ɹaɪli. sʌɾənli ʃi ɹæp mæt hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə tɑp ə ðə hɛd wɪð əɹ nʌkəlz. klæpɪŋ ə hæn tə hɪz skælp, hi stɛɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "aɪm vɛɹi hæpi ðət jə ʃoʊ lɔɪəlti tə taɪlɪn, tɔɪ," ʃi toʊld ɪm ɪn ə səvɪɹ vɔɪs, "bʌɾ aɪ woʊn əv supɝstɪʃən ɪn ju. əl nɑɾ əv ɪt. ɪt dʌz taɪlɪn noʊ ɑnɝ." bɝn hɪm, taɪlɪnz dɛθ sim tə kənsɝn əɹ əz lɪɾəl əz wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt sjuɹɔθ kəmɪɾəd suəsaɪd. wʌt kaɪndə wʊmən wɑz i ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɛɹi?

"Well, enough of that. Mat, she could have had a hundred guards around her, and it wouldn't have stopped that thing." She would not have needed a hundred guards if she had not taken up with Mat Cauthon. "A gholam," Tuon murmured wryly. Suddenly she rapped Mat hard on the top of the head with her knuckles. Clapping a hand to his scalp, he stared over his shoulder incredulously. "I'm very happy that you show loyalty to Tylin, Toy," she told him in a severe voice, "but I won't have superstition in you. I will not have it. It does Tylin no honor." Burn him, Tylin's death seemed to concern her as little as whether or not Suroth committed suicide. What kind of woman was he going to marry?
