wən ə fɪs paʊndɪɾ ɑn ðə dɔɹ ðɪs taɪm, hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ tə stænd. hi fɛl nʌm ət ðə kɔɹ ən skɹeɪpt ɹɔ ɑn ðə sɝfəs. blɹɪk pʊʃt ɪndə ðə wæɡən wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ, hɪz dɑɹk bɹaʊn kloʊk dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɹeɪn. ɪt wɑz ən oʊl kloʊk, wɔɹn θɪn ɪn spɑts, bʌɾ i əpɪɹd nɑt tə kɛɹ wɛðɝ ɹeɪn lik θɹu. ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt mæt, əɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn. ðə mæn æktʃəli  tʊk ə moʊmən tə kənsɪɾɝ sɪlutʃəz bʊzəm! "dʒoʊlin wɑns ju, kɔθən," hi sɛd, stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. laɪt!

When a fist pounded on the door this time, he did not even bother to stand. He felt numb at the core and scraped raw on the surface. Blaeric pushed into the wagon without asking, his dark brown cloak dripping rain. It was an old cloak, worn thin in spots, but he appeared not to care whether rain leaked through. The Warder ignored everyone but Mat, or almost everyone. The man actually took a moment to consider Selucia's bosom! "Joline wants you, Cauthon," he said, still studying her. Light!

ðɪs wɑz ɔl mæt niɾəd tə meɪk ɪɾ ə faɪn deɪ.

This was all Mat needed to make it a fine day.

"hu ɪz dʒoʊlin?" tuɑn dɪmændəd.

"Who is Joline?" Tuon demanded.

mæt ɪɡnɔɹd hɝ. "tɛl dʒoʊlin əl si hɝ wʌns wɝ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, blɹɪk." ðə læs θɪŋ i wɑntəd wɑz tə bi fɔɹs tə lɪsən tə mɔɹ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡɹivənsəz naʊ.

Mat ignored her. "Tell Joline I'll see her once we're on the road, Blaeric." The last thing he wanted was to be forced to listen to more of the Aes Sedai's grievances now.

"ʃi wɑns jə naʊ, kɔθən."

"She wants you now, Cauthon."

wɪð ə saɪ, mæt ɡɑt tə hɪz fiɾ ən ɡæðɝɾ ɪz kæp fɹəm ðə flɔɹ. blɹɪk lʊkt əz ɪf i maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə dʒɹæɡ hɪm, ʌðɝwaɪz. ɪn ɪz oʊn kɝən mud, hi θɔɾ i maɪt pʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn ðə mæn ɪf i tʃɹaɪd. ən ɡɛɾ ɪz nɛk bɹoʊkən fəɹ ɪz peɪnz; ə wɔɹɾɝ wəd nɑt teɪk ə naɪf ɪn ðə ɹɪbz laɪtli. hi wɑz fɛɹli ʃʊɹ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi daɪd ðə wʌn taɪm i wɑz əlaʊd, ən nɑɾ ɪn ən oʊl mɛmɹi. ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf nɑt tə teɪk ɹɪsks i kəd saɪdstɛp. "hu ɪz dʒoʊlin, tɔɪ?" ɪf i hæd nɑt noʊn bɛɾɝ, hi wʊɾə sɛd tuɑn saʊndəd dʒɛləs.

With a sigh, Mat got to his feet and gathered his cap from the floor. Blaeric looked as if he might try to drag him, otherwise. In his own current mood, he thought he might put a knife in the man if he tried. And get his neck broken for his pains; a Warder would not take a knife in the ribs lightly. He was fairly sure he had already died the one time he was allowed, and not in an old memory. Sure enough not to take risks he could sidestep. "Who is Joline, Toy?" If he had not known better, he would have said Tuon sounded jealous.

"ə blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi ɡɹʌmbəld, tʌɡɪŋ ðə kæp ɑn, ən ɡɑt wʌn smɔl plɛʒɝ fəɹ ðə deɪ.

"A bloody Aes Sedai," he grumbled, tugging the cap on, and got one small pleasure for the day.

tuɑnz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt ɪn ʃɑk. hi ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm ɑn ðə weɪ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd faɪn ə wɝd tə seɪ. ə vɛɹi smɔl plɛʒɝ. wʌn bʌɾɝflaɪ ɑn ə mɪɾən hip. taɪlɪn dɛd, ən ðə wɪnfmdɝz maɪt teɪk ðə bleɪm jɛt, wʌtɛvɝ tɑm sɛd. ən ðət wɑz əsaɪd fɹəm tuɑn ən ðə blʌɾi daɪs. ə vɛɹi taɪni bʌɾɝflaɪ ɑn ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ mɪɾən. ðə skaɪ wɑz fʊl ə dɑɹk klaʊdz, naʊ, ən ðə daʊnpɔɹ stɛɾi. ə soʊkɪŋ ɹeɪn, ðeɪ wʊɾə kɔld ɪt bæk hoʊm. ɪt bɪɡæn tə slɪk ɪz hɛɹ, kæp əɹ noʊ, ən sip θɹu hɪz koʊɾ əz sun əz i stɛpt aʊtsaɪd. blɹɪk hɑɹdli sim tə noʊɾəs, bɛɹli ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz kloʊk. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt fəɹ mæt tə hʌntʃ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən splæʃ θɹu ðə waɪɾənɪŋ pʌɾəlz ɑn ðə dɝt stʃɹits. baɪ ðə taɪm i kəd ɹitʃ ɪz wæɡən fəɹ ə kloʊk, hi wəd bi dʒɹɛntʃt tə ðə skɪn ɛniweɪ.

Tuon's jaw dropped in shock. He shut the door behind him on the way out before she could find a word to say. A very small pleasure. One butterfly on a midden heap. Tylin dead, and the Windfmders might take the blame yet, whatever Thom said. And that was aside from Tuon and the bloody dice. A very tiny butterfly on a very large midden. The sky was full of dark clouds, now, and the downpour steady. A soaking rain, they would have called it back home. It began to slick his hair, cap or no, and seep through his coat as soon as he stepped outside. Blaeric hardly seemed to notice, barely gathering his cloak. There was nothing for it but for Mat to hunch his shoulders and splash through the widening puddles on the dirt streets. By the time he could reach his wagon for a cloak, he would be drenched to the skin anyway.

bɪsaɪdz, ðə wɛðɝ fɪɾ ɪz spɪɹəts. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ɹeɪn əɹ noʊ ɹeɪn, ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl əmaʊn ʌv wɝk hæd bɪn dʌn ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt taɪm i wɑz ɪnsaɪd. ðə kænvəs wɔl wɑz ɡɔn əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si ɪn iðɝ dɝɛkʃən, ən hæf ðə stɔɹədʒ wæɡənz ðət hæd bɪn ɝaʊn tuɑnz wæɡən wɝ mɪsɪŋ, tu. soʊ wɝ moʊst ə ði ænəməlz ðət hæd bɪn pɪkəɾɪd ɑn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz. ə lɑɹdʒ, aɪɝn-bɑɹd keɪdʒ kənteɪnɪŋ ə blæk-meɪn laɪən tʃɹʌndəl pæs təwɔɹd ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ə plɑɾɪŋ tim, ðə hɔɹsəz əz ʌnkənsɝnd wɪð ði əpɛɹənli slipɪŋ laɪən bɪhaɪn əm əz ðeɪ wɝ wɪð ðə ʃaʊɝ. pɝfɔɹmɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkɪŋ tə ðə ɹoʊd, tu, ðoʊ haʊ ðeɪ dɪtɝmən ði ɔɹɾɝ ə livɪŋ wɑz ə mɪstɝi. moʊst ə ðə tɛns sim tə hæv vænɪʃt; ɪn wʌn pleɪs θɹi ʌv ðə bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd wæɡənz təɡɛðɝ maɪt bi mɪsɪŋ, ənʌðɝ pleɪs ɛvɹi sɛkənd wæɡən, waɪl ɛlswɛɹ ðə wæɡənz stændɪŋ ən weɪɾɪŋ stɪl simd ə sɑləd mæs. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət sɛd ðə ʃoʊfoʊk wɝ nɑt skæɾɝɪŋ wɑz lukə hɪmsɛlf, ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd kloʊk ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ɪm əɡɛns ðə wɛɾ əz i pɝeɪɾɪd əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit, stɑpɪŋ naʊ ən ðən tə klæp ə mæn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ əɹ mɝmɝ sʌmθɪŋ tə ə wʊmən ðət meɪɾ əɹ læf. ɪf ðə ʃoʊ hæd bɪn bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt, lukə wʊɾə bɪn aʊt tʃeɪsɪŋ daʊn ðoʊz u tʃɹaɪd tə liv. hi hɛl ðə ʃoʊ təɡɛðɝ əz mʌtʃ baɪ pɝsweɪʒən əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ən i nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛniwʌn liv wɪθaʊt tɔkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf hɔɹs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɑɹɡju ðɛm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. mæt nu hi ʃəd fil ɡʊɾ əbaʊt siɪŋ lukə stɪl ðɛɹ, ðoʊ ɪt hæd nɛvɝ əkɝd tə hɪm ðət ðə mæn wəd ɹʌn aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɡoʊld, bʌt ɹaɪɾ ət ðət moʊmənt, hi daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd meɪk ɪm fil ɛniθɪŋ bʌt nʌm ən æŋɡɹi.

Besides, the weather fit his spirits. To his surprise, rain or no rain, an incredible amount of work had been done in the short time he was inside. The canvas wall was gone as far as he could see in either direction, and half the storage wagons that had been around Tuon's wagon were missing, too. So were most of the animals that had been picketed on the horselines. A large, iron-barred cage containing a black-maned lion trundled past toward the road behind a plodding team, the horses as unconcerned with the apparently sleeping lion behind them as they were with the shower. Performers were already taking to the road, too, though how they determined the order of leaving was a mystery. Most of the tents seemed to have vanished; in one place three of the brightly colored wagons together might be missing, another place every second wagon, while elsewhere the wagons standing and waiting still seemed a solid mass. The only thing that said the showfolk were not scattering was Luca himself, a bright red cloak gathered around him against the wet as he paraded along the street, stopping now and then to clap a man on the shoulder or murmur something to a woman that made her laugh. If the show had been breaking apart, Luca would have been out chasing down those who tried to leave. He held the show together as much by persuasion as anything else, and he never let anyone leave without talking himself hoarse trying to argue them out of it. Mat knew he should feel good about seeing Luca still there, though it had never occurred to him that the man would run out on the gold, but right at that moment, he doubted that anything could make him feel anything but numb and angry.

ðə wæɡən ðət blɹɪk tʊk ɪm tə wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz lɑɹdʒ əz lukəz, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn waɪtwɑʃt ɹæðɝ ðən peɪntəd. ðə waɪt hæd lɔŋ sɪns ɹʌn ən stʃɹikt ən feɪɾəd, ən ðə ɹeɪn wɑz wɑʃɪŋ ɪɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ təwɔɹd ɡɹeɪ, wɛɹ ðə wʊd wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɛɹ. ðə wæɡən bɪlɔŋ tə ə kʌmpəni ʌv fulz, fɔɹ mɝoʊs mɛn u peɪntəd ðɛɹ feɪsəz fəɹ ðə ʃoʊz peɪtʃɹənz, daʊsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ wɪð wɔɾɝ ən hɪɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ wɪð ɪnfleɪɾəd pɪɡblæɾɝz, ən ʌðɝwaɪz spɛn ðɛɹ taɪm ən mʌni ɪmbəbɪŋ əz mʌtʃ waɪn əz ðeɪ kəd baɪ. wɪð wʌt mæt hæd peɪd fəɹ ɹɛnt, ðeɪ maɪt bi dʒɹʌŋk fəɹ mʌnθs, ən ɪt hæd kɑs mɔɹ ðən ðət tə meɪk ɛniwʌn teɪk əm ɪn.

The wagon that Blaeric took him to was almost as large as Luca's, but it had been whitewashed rather than painted. The white had long since run and streaked and faded, and the rain was washing it a little more toward gray, where the wood was not already bare. The wagon belonged to a company of fools, four morose men who painted their faces for the show's patrons, dousing each other with water and hitting each other with inflated pigbladders, and otherwise spent their time and money imbibing as much wine as they could buy. With what Mat had paid for rent, they might be drunk for months, and it had cost more than that to make anyone take them in.

fɔɹ ʃæɡi, nɑndɪskɹɪp hɔɹsəz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪtʃt tə ðə wæɡən, ən fɛn maɪzɑɹ, dʒoʊlinz ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ, wɑz ʌp ɑn ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz sit, swɑðd ɪn ən oʊld ɡɹeɪ kloʊk ən ɹeɪnz ɪn hænd. hɪz tɪltəɾ aɪz wɑtʃt mæt ðə weɪ ə wʊlf maɪt wɑtʃ ən ɪmpjəɾənt kɝ. ðə wɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn ənhæpi wɪð mæts plæn fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, ʃʊɹ ðeɪ cʊɾə ɡɑɾən ðə sɪstɝz əweɪ seɪfli wʌns ðeɪ wɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. pɝhæps ðeɪ kəd hæv, bʌt ðə sintʃæn hʌntəd vɪɡɝəsli fəɹ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl - ðə ʃoʊ ɪtsɛlf əpɛɹənli hæd bɪn sɝtʃt fɔɹ taɪmz ɪn ðə deɪz æftɝ ɛbu dɑɹ fɛl - ən ɔl ɪt wʊɾə teɪkən wɑz wʌn slɪp tə læn ɔl ə ðɛm ɪn ðə stupɑt. fɹəm wʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ən doʊmən sɛd, ðə sikɝz kəd meɪk ə boʊldɝ tɛl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪt hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. lʌkəli, nɑɾ ɔl ðə sɪstɝz wɝ əz ʃʊɹ əz dʒoʊlinz wɔɹɾɝz. ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛndəd tə dɪðɝ wən ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əɡɹi ɑn wʌt tə du.

Four shaggy, nondescript horses were already hitched to the wagon, and Fen Mizar, Joline's other Warder, was up on the driver's seat, swathed in an old gray cloak and reins in hand. His tilted eyes watched Mat the way a wolf might watch an impudent cur. The Warders had been unhappy with Mat's plan from the start, sure they could have gotten the sisters away safely once they were outside the city walls. Perhaps they could have, but the Seanchan hunted vigorously for women who could channel - the show itself apparently had been searched four times in the days after Ebou Dar fell - and all it would have taken was one slip to land all of them in the stewpot. From what Egeanin and Domon said, the Seekers could make a boulder tell everything it had ever seen. Luckily, not all the sisters were as sure as Joline's Warders. Aes Sedai tended to dither when they could not agree on what to do.

wən mæt ɹitʃt ðə stɛps ət ðə bæk ə ðə wæɡən, blɹɪk stɑpt ɪm wɪð ə hæn tə hɪz tʃɛst. ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹvd, noʊ mɔɹ kənsɝn ðən ə pis ʌv wʊd wɪð ðə ɹeɪn ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ɪz tʃiks. "fɛn ən aɪ ɑɹ ɡɹeɪtfəl tə jə fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, kɔθən, bʌt ðɪs kæn kəntɪnju. ðə sɪstɝz ɑɹ kɹaʊɾəd, ʃɛɹɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz ʌðɝ wɪmən, ən ðeɪ doʊnt ɡɛɾ ɑn. ðəɹ ɪz gɑnə bi tʃɹʌbəl ɪf wi kæn faɪn ənʌðɝ wæɡən."

When Mat reached the steps at the back of the wagon, Blaeric stopped him with a hand to his chest. The Warder's face might have been carved, no more concerned than a piece of wood with the rain running down his cheeks. "Fen and I are grateful to you for getting her out of the city, Cauthon, but this can't continue. The sisters are crowded, sharing with those other women, and they don't get on. There is going to be trouble if we can't find another wagon."

"ɪz ðət wʌt ðɪs ɪz əbaʊt?" mæt sɛd kɹɑsli, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz kɑlɝ taɪɾɝ. nɑt ðəɾ ɪt dɪd mʌtʃ ɡʊd. hi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wɛt θɹu ɑn ðə bæk, ən nɑt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ɪn fɹʌnt. ɪf dʒoʊlin hæd pʊld ɪm hɪɹ tə waɪn əbaʊt ði əkɑmədeɪʃənz əɡɛn. . . . "ʃil tɛl jə wʌɾ ɪts əbaʊt, kɔθən. dʒʌs jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ sɛd."

"Is that what this is about?" Mat said crossly, tugging his collar tighter. Not that it did much good. He was already wet through on the back, and not much better in front. If Joline had pulled him here to whine about the accommodations again. . . . "She'll tell you what it's about, Cauthon. Just you remember what I said."

ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, mæt klaɪm ðə dɝt-stʃɹik stɛps ən wɛn ɪn, nɑt kwaɪt slæmɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə wæɡən wɑz leɪɾ aʊt mʌtʃ laɪk ðə wʌn tuɑn wɑz ɪn, ðoʊ wɪð fɔɹ bɛdz, tu ʌv əm foʊldəd flæɾ əɡɛns ðə wɔlz əbʌv ði ʌðɝ tu. hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə haʊ ðə sɪks wɪmən ɝeɪnʒd slipɪŋ, bʌɾ i səspɛktəɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt dʌn pisfəli. ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə wæɡən ɔl bʌt kɹækəld laɪk ɡɹis ɑn ə ɡɹɪɾəl. θɹi wɪmən sæɾ ɑn itʃ ə ðə loʊɝ bɛdz, itʃ vɛɹiəsli wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə wɪmən siɾəd ɑn ði ʌðɝ bɛd. dʒoʊlin, hu hæd nɛvɝ bɪn hɛld əz deɪmeɪn bɪheɪvd əz ðoʊ ðə θɹi sʌldəm dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst. ɹiɾɪŋ ə smɔl wʊd-baʊn bʊk, ʃi wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ði ɪntʃ ən ɛɹəɡəns ɑn ə stɪk dɪspaɪɾ əɹ wɛl-wɔɹn blu dʒɹɛs, leɪtli oʊn baɪ ə wʊmən u tɔt ðə laɪənz tə də tʃɹɪks. ði ʌðɝ tu sɪstɝz nu fɝsthænd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə bi deɪmeɪn, ðoʊ. idɛzinə wɑtʃt ðə θɹi sʌldəm wɛɹəli, wʌn hæn ɹɛstɪŋ nɪɹ əɹ bɛl naɪf, waɪl tɛslɪnz aɪz ʃɪftəd kɑnstənli, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə sʌldəm, ən əɹ hænz niɾɪd əɹ dɑɹk wʊlən skɝts. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ ɛdʒiənɪn hæd koʊɝs ðə θɹi sʌldəm ɪndə hɛlpɪŋ deɪmeɪn ɪskeɪp, bʌɾ ivən ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ sɔt baɪ ði əθɔɹəɾiz əz ʃʊɹli əz ɛdʒiənɪn, ðeɪ hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ æɾətudz təwɔɹd wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl. bɛθəmən, tɔl ən əz dɑɹk əz tuɑn ɪn ən ɛbu dɑɹi dʒɹɛs wɪð ə vɛɹi dip nɛklaɪn ən skɝts soʊn ʌp əbʌv əɹ ni ɑn wʌn saɪd tə ʃoʊ feɪɾəd ɹɛd pɛɾikoʊts, simd ə mʌðɝ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪnɛvəɾəbəl mɪsbəheɪvjɝ baɪ tʃɪlʒɹən, waɪl jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sɛɾə, ɪn haɪ-nɛkt ɡɹeɪ wʊl ðət kʌvɝɾ əɹ kəmplitli, əpɪɹd tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs dɑɡz ðət wəd nid tə bi keɪdʒ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. ɹɛnə, ʃi ʌv ðə tɔk əbaʊt kʌɾɪŋ ɔf hænz ən fit, pɹitɛndəd tə bi ɹiɾɪŋ, tu, bʌɾ ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən əɹ dɪsɛptɪvli maɪl bɹaʊn aɪz ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə slɪm vɑljum tə stʌɾi ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən wən ðeɪ dɪd, ʃi smaɪld ɪn ən ənplɛzənt weɪ. mæt fɛlt laɪk kɝsɪŋ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðɛm oʊpən əɹ maʊð. ə waɪz mæn kɛp klɪɹ wən wɪmən wɝ əɾ ɑdz, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ əmʌŋ ðɛm, bʌt ðɪs wɑz haʊ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz wɑz wən i keɪm tə ðɪs wæɡən.

Grumbling under his breath, Mat climbed the dirt-streaked steps and went in, not quite slamming the door behind him. The wagon was laid out much like the one Tuon was in, though with four beds, two of them folded flat against the walls above the other two. He had no idea how the six women arranged sleeping, but he suspected it was not done peacefully. The air in the wagon all but crackled like grease on a griddle. Three women sat on each of the lower beds, each variously watching or ignoring the women seated on the other bed. Joline, who had never been held as damane behaved as though the three sul'dam did not exist. Reading a small wood-bound book, she was an Aes Sedai to the inch and arrogance on a stick despite her well-worn blue dress, lately owned by a woman who taught the lions to do tricks. The other two sisters knew firsthand what it was to be damane, though. Edesina watched the three sul'dam warily, one hand resting near her belt knife, while Teslyn's eyes shifted constantly, looking at anything except the sul'dam, and her hands kneaded her dark woolen skirts. He did not know how Egeanin had coerced the three sul'dam into helping damane escape, but even though they were being sought by the authorities as surely as Egeanin, they had not changed their attitudes toward women who could channel. Bethamin, tall and as dark as Tuon in an Ebou Dari dress with a very deep neckline and skirts sewn up above her knee on one side to show faded red petticoats, seemed a mother waiting for inevitable misbehavior by children, while yellow-haired Seta, in high-necked gray wool that covered her completely, appeared to be studying dangerous dogs that would need to be caged sooner or later. Renna, she of the talk about cutting off hands and feet, pretended to be reading, too, but every so often her deceptively mild brown eyes rose from the slim volume to study the Aes Sedai, and when they did, she smiled in an unpleasant way. Mat felt like cursing before one of them opened her mouth. A wise man kept clear when women were at odds, especially if there were Aes Sedai among them, but this was how it always was when he came to this wagon.

"ðɪs bɛɾɝ bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt, dʒoʊlin." ənbʌtoʊnɪŋ ɪz koʊt, hi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃeɪk səm ə ðə wɔɾɝ ɔf.

"This better be important, Joline." Unbuttoning his coat, he tried to shake some of the water off.

hi θɔɾ i wəd də bɛɾɝ ɹɪŋɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹmən aʊt. "aɪ dʒʌs lɝn ðət ðə ɡoʊləm kɪl taɪlɪn ðə naɪt wi lɛft, ən aɪm ɪn noʊ mud fəɹ kəmpleɪns." dʒoʊlin mɑɹkt əɹ pleɪs kɛɹfəli wɪð ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd mɑɹkɝ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðə bʊk bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ hɝid; ðeɪ dʒʌst ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls tə. wɪθaʊt hɪm, ʃi laɪkli wʊɾə bɪn wɛɹɪŋ ən æɾəm baɪ naʊ hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ faʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli noʊɾəd fəɹ ɡɹæɾətud, iðɝ. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd wʌɾ i hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt taɪlɪn. "blɹɪk tɛlz mi ðə ʃoʊ hæz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn muvɪŋ," ʃi sɛd kuli, "bʌt jə mʌst stɑp ɪt. lukə wɪl oʊnli lɪsən tə ju." hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd slaɪtli ɑn ðə wɝdz. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlsoʊ wɝ ənjuz tə nɑt biɪŋ lɪsən tə, ən ɡɹinz wɝ nɑt ðə bɛst ət haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ. "wi mʌst əbændən ði aɪdiə ʌv luɡɹd fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. wi mʌs teɪk ðə fɛɹi əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ ən ɡoʊ tə ɪljən."

He thought he would do better wringing the garment out. "I just learned that the gholam killed Tylin the night we left, and I'm in no mood for complaints." Joline marked her place carefully with an embroidered marker and folded her hands on the book before speaking. Aes Sedai never hurried; they just expected everyone else to. Without him, she likely would have been wearing an a'dam by now herself, but he had never found Aes Sedai particularly noted for gratitude, either. She ignored what he had said about Tylin. "Blaeric tells me the show has already begun moving," she said coolly, "but you must stop it. Luca will only listen to you." Her mouth tightened slightly on the words. Aes Sedai also were unused to not being listened to, and Greens were not the best at hiding their displeasure. "We must abandon the idea of Lugard for the time being. We must take the ferry across the harbor and go to Illian."

ðət wɑz əbaʊɾ əz bæɾ ə sədʒɛstʃən əz i hæd hɝɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt min ɪt fəɹ ə sədʒɛstʃən, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃi wɑz wɝs ðən ɛdʒiənɪn ðət weɪ. wɪð hæf ðə ʃoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ɪt wəd teɪk ɔl deɪ dʒʌs tə ɡɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn daʊn tə ðə fɛɹi lændɪŋ, ən ɪt wəd min ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, bɪsaɪdz. hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ luɡɹd tʊk ðə ʃoʊ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl, waɪl ðeɪ hæd soʊlʒɝz kæmpt ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði ɪljən bɔɹɾɝ ən meɪbi bɪɑnd. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə tɛl wʌt ʃi nu, bʌt tɑm hæɾ ɪz weɪz ə lɝnɪŋ ðiz θɪŋz. mæt dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə kɹæk ɪz tiθ, ðoʊ. hi dɪd nɑt nid tə.

That was about as bad a suggestion as he had heard out of her, though she did not mean it for a suggestion, of course; she was worse than Egeanin that way. With half the show already on the road, or near enough, it would take all day just to get everyone down to the ferry landing, and it would mean going into the city, besides. Heading for Lugard took the show away from the Seanchan as quickly as possible, while they had soldiers camped all the way to the Illian border and maybe beyond. Egeanin was reluctant to tell what she knew, but Thom had his ways of learning these things. Mat did not bother to crack his teeth, though. He did not need to.

"noʊ," tɛslɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs, hɝ ɪliɑnɝ æksɛn stʃɹɔŋ. linɪŋ pæst idɛzinə, ʃi lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi tʃud ɹɑks θɹi milz ə deɪ, hɑɹd-feɪst ən sɛt-dʒɔd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə nɝvəsnəs ɪn əɹ aɪz, pʊt ðəɹ baɪ hɝ wiks əz ə deɪmənz. "noʊ, dʒoʊlin. aɪ hæv toʊl ju, wi də noʊ dɛɹ ɹɪsk ɪt! wi də noʊ dɛɹ!"

"No," Teslyn said in a tight voice, her Illianer accent strong. Leaning past Edesina, she looked as though she chewed rocks three meals a day, hard-faced and set-jawed, but there was a nervousness in her eyes, put there by her weeks as a damans. "No, Joline. I have told you, we do no dare risk it! We do no dare!"

"laɪt!" dʒoʊlin spæt, slæmɪŋ əɹ bʊk tə ðə flɔɹ. "teɪk hoʊld ə jɝsɛlf, tɛslɪn! dʒʌs kəz jə wɝ hɛl pɹɪznɝ fəɹ ə lɪɾəl taɪm ɪz noʊ ɹizən tə ɡoʊ tə pisəz!"

"Light!" Joline spat, slamming her book to the floor. "Take hold of yourself, Teslyn! Just because you were held prisoner for a little time is no reason to go to pieces!"

"ɡoʊ tə pisəz? ɡoʊ tə pisəz? lɛɾ əm pʊt ðət kɑlɝ ɑn jə ən ðən spik ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ tə pisəz!" tɛslɪnz hænd wɛn tə hɝ θɹoʊɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi fɛl ði æɾəmz kɑlɝ stɪl. "hɛlp mi kənvɪns hɝ, idɛzinə. ʃɪl əv əs kɑlɝɾ əɡɛn, ɪf wi də lɛt hɝ!" idɛzinə dʒɹu bæk ɑn hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪhaɪn ðə bɛd - ə slɪm, hænsəm wʊmən wɪð blæk hɛɹ spɪlɪŋ tə hɝ weɪst, ʃi ɔlweɪz wɛn saɪlənt wən ðə ɹɛɾ ən ðə ɡɹin ɑɹɡjud, əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɔfən - bʌt dʒoʊlin dɪd nɑt spɛɹ əɹ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns. "ju æsk ə ɹɛbəl fəɹ hɛlp, tɛslɪn? wi ʃʊɾə lɛft əɹ fəɹ ðə sintʃæn! lɪsən tə mi. jə kən fil ɪɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ. wəd jə ɹɪli æksɛpt ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ deɪnʒɝ tə əvɔɪɾ ə lɛsɝ?" "lɛsɝ!" tɛslɪn snɑɹəld. "ju də noʊ nʌθɪŋ ʌv - !" ɹɛnə hɛld əɹ bʊk aʊɾ əɾ ɑɹmz lɛŋθ ən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɑp tə ðə flɔɹ wɪð ə bæŋ. "ɪf maɪ lɔɹd wɪl ɪkskjuz əs ə lɪɾəl waɪl, wi stɪl əv əɹ æɾəm, ən wi kən titʃ ðiz ɡɝlz tə bɪheɪv əɡɛn ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ." hɝ æksɛn hæɾ ə mjuzɪkəl kwɑləɾi, bʌt ðə smaɪl ɑn əɹ lɪps nɛvɝ tʌtʃt əɹ bɹaʊn aɪz. "ɪt nɛvɝ wɝks tə lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ slæk ðɪs weɪ." sɛɾə nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli ən stʊɾ əz ɪf tə fɛtʃ aʊt ðə liʃɪz.

"Go to pieces? Go to pieces? Let them put that collar on you and then speak of going to pieces!" Teslyn's hand went to her throat as though she felt the a'dam's collar still. "Help me convince her, Edesina. She will have us collared again, if we do let her!" Edesina drew back on herself against the wall behind the bed - a slim, handsome woman with black hair spilling to her waist, she always went silent when the Red and the Green argued, as they did often - but Joline did not spare her so much as a glance. "You ask a rebel for help, Teslyn? We should have left her for the Seanchan! Listen to me. You can feel it as well as I. Would you really accept a greater danger to avoid a lesser?" "Lesser!" Teslyn snarled. "You do know nothing of - !" Renna held her book out at arm's length and let it drop to the floor with a bang. "If my Lord will excuse us a little while, we still have our a'dam, and we can teach these girls to behave again in short order." Her accent had a musical quality, but the smile on her lips never touched her brown eyes. "It never works to let them go slack this way." Seta nodded grimly and stood as if to fetch out the leashes.

"aɪ θɪŋk wɝ dʌn wɪð æɾəm," bɛθəmən sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ʃɑk lʊks fɹəm ði ʌðɝ tu sʌldəm, "bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ weɪz tə sɛɾəl ðiz ɡɝlz daʊn. meɪ aɪ sədʒɛs maɪ lɔɹd ɹɪtɝn ɪn ən aʊɝ?

"I think we're done with a'dam," Bethamin said, ignoring the shocked looks from the other two sul'dam, "but there are other ways to settle these girls down. May I suggest my Lord return in an hour?

ðəl tɛl jə wʌt jə wɑnə noʊ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni skwɑbəlɪŋ wʌns ðeɪ kæn sɪt daʊn." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi mɛn ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi sɛd. dʒoʊlin wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə θɹi sʌldəm ɪn aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ dɪsbɪlif, bʌɾ idɛzinə wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ bɛl naɪf wɪð ə dɪtɝmən ɪkspɹɛʃən, waɪl tɛslɪn wɑz naʊ ðə wʌn ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hɝ hænz klæsp taɪtli əɾ əɹ weɪst.

They'll tell you what you want to know without any squabbling once they can't sit down." She sounded as though she meant exactly what she said. Joline was staring at the three sul'dam in outraged disbelief, but Edesina was sitting up straight, gripping her belt knife with a determined expression, while Teslyn was now the one shrinking back against the wall, her hands clasped tightly at her waist.

"ðæt woʊn bi nɛsəsɛɹi," mæt sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. oʊnli ə moʊmənt. haʊɛvɝ sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ ɪt maɪt bi tə hæv dʒoʊlin "sɛɾəld daʊn," idɛzinə maɪt dʒɹɔ ðət naɪf, ən ðət wəd sɛt ðə kæɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɪkənz noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɪt tɝn aʊt. "wʌt ɡɹeɪɾɝ deɪnʒɝ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, dʒoʊlin? dʒoʊlin?

"That won't be necessary," Mat said after a moment. Only a moment. However satisfying it might be to have Joline "settled down," Edesina might draw that knife, and that would set the cat among the chickens no matter how it turned out. "What greater danger are you talking about, Joline? Joline?

wʌt deɪnʒɝ ɪz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðə sintʃæn ɹaɪt naʊ?"

What danger is greater than the Seanchan right now?"

ðə ɡɹin dɪsaɪɾɪd əɹ stɛɹ wɑz meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn bɛθəmən ən tɝn ɪɾ ɑn mæt, ɪnstɛd. hæd ʃi bɪn ʌðɝ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi wʊɾə sɛd ʃi lʊk sʌlki. dʒoʊlin dɪslaɪkt ɪkspleɪnɪŋ. "ɪf jə mʌs noʊ, sʌmwʌn ɪz tʃænəlɪŋ." tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə nɑɾəd, ðə ɹɛd sɪstɝ ɹɪlʌktənli, ðə jɛloʊ ɛmfæɾɪkli.

The Green decided her stare was making no impression on Bethamin and turned it on Mat, instead. Had she been other than Aes Sedai, he would have said she looked sulky. Joline disliked explaining. "If you must know, someone is channeling." Teslyn and Edesina nodded, the Red sister reluctantly, the Yellow emphatically.

"ɪn ðə kæmp?" hi sɛɾ ɪn əlɑɹm. hɪz ɹaɪt hæn ɹoʊz ɑn ɪts oʊn tə pɹɛs əɡɛns ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ʃɝt, bʌt ðə mədæljən hæd nɑt tɝn koʊld.

"In the camp?" he said in alarm. His right hand rose on its own to press against the silver foxhead under his shirt, but the medallion had not turned cold.

"fɑɹ əweɪ," dʒoʊlin ɹɪplaɪd, stɪl ənwɪlɪŋ. "tə ðə nɔɹθ." "mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ ðən ɛni ʌv əs ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə sɛns tʃænəlɪŋ," idɛzinə pʊɾ ɪn, ə tʌtʃ ə fɪɹ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "ði əmaʊn ə seɪaɪdɑɹ biɪŋ wildɪd mʌs bi ɪmɛns, ɪnkənsivəbəl." ʃi fɛl saɪlən əɾ ə ʃɑɹp ɡlæns fɹəm dʒoʊlin, hu tɝn bæk tə stʌɾi mæt əz ðoʊ dəsaɪɾɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi hæd tə tɛl hɪm. "æt ðət dɪstəns," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "wi wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə fil ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ tʃænəlɪŋ. ɪts tə bi ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ən wʌtɛvɝ ðəɹ duɪŋ, wi də nɑt wɑnə bi ɛni kloʊsɝ ðən wi kən əvɔɪd." mæt wɑz stɪl fəɹ ə moʊmənt; ðən faɪnəli, hi sɛd, "ɪf ɪts fɑɹ, ðən wi stɪk wɪð ðə plæn." dʒoʊlin wɛn ɑn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə lɪsən. wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ ə ɹænd əɹ pɛɹɪn, kʌlɝz swɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd. ə pɑɹɾ ə biɪŋ tɑvɝən, hi səpoʊzd. ðɪs taɪm, hi hæd nɑt θɔɾ ʌv iðɝ ə hɪz fɹɛnz, bʌt ðə kʌlɝz hæd sʌɾənli bɪn ðɛɹ, ə fæn ʌv ə θaʊzən ɹeɪnboʊz. ðɪs taɪm, ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlmoʊs fɔɹmd ən ɪmədʒ, ə veɪɡ ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ə mæn ən ə wʊmən siɾəd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn feɪsɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən ɪnstənt, bʌɾ i nu əz ʃʊɹli əz i nu hɪz neɪm. nɑt ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ɹænd. ən i kəd nɑt hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ, wʌt hæd ɹænd bɪn duɪŋ wən ðə daɪs stɑpt?

"Far away," Joline replied, still unwilling. "To the north." "Much farther than any of us should be able to sense channeling," Edesina put in, a touch of fear in her voice. "The amount of saidar being wielded must be immense, inconceivable." She fell silent at a sharp glance from Joline, who turned back to study Mat as though deciding how much she had to tell him. "At that distance," she went on, "we wouldn't be able to feel every sister in the Tower channeling. It has to be the Forsaken, and whatever they're doing, we do not want to be any closer than we can avoid." Mat was still for a moment; then finally, he said, "If it's far, then we stick with the plan." Joline went on arguing, but he did not bother to listen. Whenever he thought of Rand or Perrin, colors swirled in his head. A part of being ta'veren, he supposed. This time, he had not thought of either of his friends, but the colors had suddenly been there, a fan of a thousand rainbows. This time, they had almost formed an image, a vague impression that might have been a man and a woman seated on the ground facing one another. It was gone in an instant, but he knew as surely as he knew his name. Not the Forsaken. Rand. And he could not help wondering, what had Rand been doing when the dice stopped?

tʃæptɝ fɔɹ

CHAPTER 4

ðə teɪl ʌv ə dɑl fɹɪk kɛɹid sæt stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ðə peɪpɝz ən mæps spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. boʊθ ə hɪz ɔɪl læmps wɝ lɪɾ ən sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, bʌɾ i noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæd niɾ ə ðɛm.

The Tale of a Doll Furyk Karede sat staring at his writing table without seeing the papers and maps spread out in front of him. Both of his oil lamps were lit and sitting on the table, but he no longer had need of them.

ðə sʌn mʌs bi ɹɪmɪŋ ðə hɝaɪzən, jɛt sɪns weɪkɪŋ fɹəm ə fɪtfəl slip ən seɪɪŋ ɪz dɪvoʊʃənz tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, hi hæɾ oʊnli dɑn ɪz ɹoʊb, ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɪmpɪɹiəl ɡɹin ðət səm ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn kɔlɪŋ blæk, ən sæt hɪɹ wɪθaʊt muvɪŋ sɪns. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən ʃeɪvd. ðə ɹeɪn hæd stɑpt, ən i kənsɪɾɝd tɛlɪŋ ɪz sɝvən ædʒɪmbʊɹə tə swɪŋ ə wɪndoʊ oʊpən fəɹ ə lɪɾəl fɹɛʃ ɛɹ ɪn ɪz ɹum ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən. klin ɛɹ maɪt klɪɹ ɪz hɛd. bʌɾ oʊvɝ ðə læs faɪv deɪz ðəɹ hæd bɪn lʌlz ɪn ðə ɹeɪn ðəɾ ɛndəd wɪð sʌɾən dʒɹɛntʃɪŋ daʊnpɔɹz, ən ɪz bɛd wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd bɪtwin ðə wɪndoʊz. hi hæd niɾəd tə hæv ɪz mætʃɹəs ən bɛɾɪŋ hʌŋ ɪn ðə kɪtʃən tə dʒɹaɪ wʌns ɔlɹɛɾi.

The sun must be rimming the horizon, yet since waking from a fitful sleep and saying his devotions to the Empress, might she live forever, he had only donned his robe, in the dark Imperial green that some insisted on calling black, and sat here without moving since. He had not even shaved. The rain had stopped, and he considered telling his servant Ajimbura to swing a window open for a little fresh air in his room at The Wandering Woman. Clean air might clear his head. But over the last five days there had been lulls in the rain that ended with sudden drenching downpours, and his bed was located between the windows. He had needed to have his mattress and bedding hung in the kitchen to dry once already.

ə taɪni skwil ən ə plizd ɡɹʌn fɹəm ædʒɪmbʊɹə meɪɾ ɪm lʊk ʌp tə faɪn ðə wɪɹi lɪɾəl mæn dɪspleɪɪŋ ə lɪmp ɹæt hæf ðə saɪz ʌv ə kæɾ ɑn ði ɛn ə hɪz lɔŋ naɪf. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝst ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd kɪld ɪn ðɪs ɹum ɹisənli, sʌmθɪŋ kɛɹid bɪlivd wəd nɑɾ əv hæpən ɪf sɛɾəl ɑnən stɪl oʊn ði ɪn, ðoʊ ðə nʌmbɝ ə ɹæts ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ sim tə bi ɪnkɹisɪŋ wɛl ɪn ədvæns ə spɹɪŋ. ædʒɪmbʊɹə lʊkt ə lɪɾəl laɪk ə waɪzən ɹæt hɪmsɛlf, hɪz ɡɹɪn boʊθ sæɾəsfaɪd ən fɛɹəl. æftɝ mɔɹ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ʌndɝ ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ðə kɛnsɑɾə hɪl tʃɹaɪbz wɝ oʊnli hæf sɪvəlaɪzd, ən lɛs ðən hæf teɪmd. ðə mæn wɔɹ ɪz waɪt-stʃɹik dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ ɪn ə θɪk bɹeɪd ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz weɪst, tə meɪk ə ɡʊd tʃɹoʊfi ɪf i ɛvɝ faʊn ɪz weɪ bæk tə ðoʊz nɪɹ-maʊntənz ən fɛl ɪn wʌn ə ði ɛnləs fjudz bɪtwin fæmliz əɹ tʃɹaɪbz, ən i ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ fɹəm ə sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd kʌp ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u lʊkt kloʊsli kəd si wɑz ðə tɑp ə sʌmwʌnz skʌl.

A tiny squeal and a pleased grunt from Ajimbura made him look up to find the wiry little man displaying a limp rat half the size of a cat on the end of his long knife. It was not the first Ajimbura had killed in this room recently, something Karede believed would not have happened if Setalle Anan still owned the inn, though the number of rats in Ebou Dar seemed to be increasing well in advance of spring. Ajimbura looked a little like a wizened rat himself, his grin both satisfied and feral. After more than three hundred years under the Empire, the Kaensada hill tribes were only half civilized, and less than half tamed. The man wore his white-streaked dark red hair in a thick braid that hung to his waist, to make a good trophy if he ever found his way back to those near-mountains and fell in one of the endless feuds between families or tribes, and he insisted on drinking from a silver-mounted cup that anyone who looked closely could see was the top of someone's skull.

"ɪf jə ɑɹ gɑnə it ðæt," kɛɹid sɛɾ əz ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ ɛni kwɛstʃən, "ju wɪl klin ɪɾ ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛniwʌnz saɪt." ædʒɪmbʊɹə wəɾ iɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp fəɹ lɪzɝdz, wɪtʃ wɝ fɔɹbɪɾən tə hɪz tʃɹaɪb fəɹ səm ɹizən i wəd nɛvɝ meɪk klɪɹ.

"If you are going to eat that," Karede said as though there were any question, "you will clean it in the stableyard out of anyone's sight." Ajimbura would eat anything except for lizards, which were forbidden to his tribe for some reason he would never make clear.

"bʌɾ ə kɔɹs, haɪ wʌn," ðə mæn ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ðə hʌntʃ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ðət pæs fəɹ ə baʊ əmʌŋ ɪz pipəl. "aɪ noʊ wɛl ðə weɪz ə ðə taʊnzpipəl, ən aɪ wəd nɑɾ ɪmbɛɹəs ðə haɪ wʌn." æftɝ kloʊs tə twɛnti jɪɹz ɪn kɛɹidz sɝvəs, wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹimaɪndɝ i stɪl wʊɾə skɪn aʊt ðə ɹæɾ ən ɹoʊstəɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz ɪn ðə smɔl bɹɪk faɪɝpleɪs.

"But of course, high one," the man replied with the hunch of his shoulders that passed for a bow among his people. "I know well the ways of the townspeople, and I would not embarrass the high one." After close to twenty years in Karede's service, without a reminder he still would have skinned out the rat and roasted it over the flames in the small brick fireplace.

skɹeɪpɪŋ ðə kɑɹkəs ɔf ðə bleɪɾ ɪndə ə smɔl kænvəs sæk, ædʒɪmbʊɹə tʌk ðəɾ ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ fəɹ leɪɾɝ ən kɛɹfəli waɪpt ɪz naɪf klin bɪfɔɹ ʃiðɪŋ ɪɾ ən sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn ɪz hilz tə əweɪt kɛɹidz nidz. hi wəd weɪt laɪk ðəɾ ɔl deɪ, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, əz peɪʃənli əz ə dækoʊvæl. kɛɹid hæd nɛvɝ pʌzəld aʊɾ ɪɡzækli waɪ ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd lɛft ɪz hɪl fɔɹt hoʊm tə fɑloʊ wʌn ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd. ɪt wɑz ə mʌtʃ mɔɹ sɝkəmskɹaɪb laɪf ðən ðə mæn hæd noʊn bɪfɔɹ, ən bɪsaɪdz, kɛɹid hæd nɪɹli kɪld ɪm θɹi taɪmz bɪfɔɹ i meɪd ðət tʃɔɪs.

Scraping the carcass off the blade into a small canvas sack, Ajimbura tucked that into a corner for later and carefully wiped his knife clean before sheathing it and settling on his heels to await Karede's needs. He would wait like that all day, if necessary, as patiently as a da'covale. Karede had never puzzled out exactly why Ajimbura had left his hill fort home to follow one of the Deathwatch Guard. It was a much more circumscribed life than the man had known before, and besides, Karede had nearly killed him three times before he made that choice.

dɪsmɪsɪŋ θɔts ə hɪz sɝvənt, hi ɹɪtɝn tə ðə dɪspleɪ ɑn ɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ðoʊ hi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə teɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz pɛn fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. hi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz tə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl fəɹ ətʃivɪŋ səm smɔl səksɛs ɪn ðə bæɾəlz wɪð ði æʃəmən, ɪn deɪz wən fju hæɾ ətʃivd ɛni, ən naʊ, kəz i hæd kəmændəɾ əɡɛns mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, səm θɔɾ i mʌst əv wɪzdəm tə ʃɛɹ əbaʊt faɪɾɪŋ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. noʊ wʌn hæd hæd tə də ðəɾ ɪn sɛntʃɝiz, ən sɪns ðə soʊ-kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪvil ðɛɹ ənnoʊn wɛpən oʊnli ə fju liɡz fɹəm wɛɹ i sæt, ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə θɪŋkɪŋ hæd ɡɔn ɪndə haʊ tə kɹɪpəl ðɛɹ paʊɝ. ðət wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɹɪkwɛs lɪɾɝɪŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp. əsaɪd fɹəm ðə juʒəwəl ɹʌn ə ɹɛkwəzɪʃənz ən ɹɪpɔɹts ðət niɾəd ɪz sɪɡnətʃɝ, hɪz kɑmɛns ɑn ðə fɔɹsɪz ɝeɪɾ əɡɛnst əm ɪn ɪljən hæd bɪn səlɪsɪɾɪd baɪ fɔɹ lɔɹdz ən θɹi leɪɾiz, ən ɑn ðə spɛʃəl il pɹɑbləm baɪ sɪks leɪɾiz ən faɪv lɔɹdz, bʌt ðoʊz kwɛstʃənz wəd bi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛlswɛɹ, vɛɹi laɪkli ɔlɹɛɾi hæd bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd. hɪz ɑbzɝveɪʃənz wəɾ oʊnli bi juzd ɪn ði ɪnfaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ u kəntʃɹoʊld wʌɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪtɝn. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, wɔɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə sɛkən kɔlɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd. oʊ, ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ ɔlweɪz ðəɹ wɛnɛvɝ ə meɪdʒɝ bæɾəl wɑz fɔt, ðə sɔɹdhæn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, tə stʃɹaɪk əɾ əɹ ɛnəmiz wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz pɹɛzənt, ɔlweɪz tə lid ðə weɪ wɛɹ ðə faɪt wɑz hɑɾəst, bʌt ðɛɹ fɝs kɔlɪŋ wɑz tə pɹətɛk ðə laɪvz ən pɝsənz ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli.

Dismissing thoughts of his servant, he returned to the display on his writing table, though he had no intention of taking up his pen for the moment. He had been raised to banner-general for achieving some small success in the battles with the Asha'man, in days when few had achieved any, and now, because he had commanded against men who could channel, some thought he must have wisdom to share about fighting marath'damane. No one had had to do that in centuries, and since the so-called Aes Sedai revealed their unknown weapon only a few leagues from where he sat, a great deal of thinking had gone into how to cripple their power. That was not the only request littering the tabletop. Aside from the usual run of requisitions and reports that needed his signature, his comments on the forces arrayed against them in Illian had been solicited by four lords and three ladies, and on the special Aiel problem by six ladies and five lords, but those questions would be decided elsewhere, very likely already had been decided. His observations would only be used in the infighting over who controlled what in the Return. In any event, war had always been a second calling for the Deathwatch Guard. Oh, the Guards were always there whenever a major battle was fought, the swordhand of the Empress, might she live forever, to strike at her enemies whether or not she herself was present, always to lead the way where the fight was hottest, but their first calling was to protect the lives and persons of the Imperial family.

wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn laɪvz, wən nɛsəsɛɹi, ən wɪlɪŋli ɡɪvən. ən naɪn naɪts pæst, ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn hæd vænɪʃt əz ɪf swɑloʊd baɪ ðə stɔɹm. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə hɝ əz ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, kəd nɑɾ əntɪl i nu ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʌndɝ ðə veɪl. hi hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd teɪkɪŋ ɪz oʊn laɪf, iðɝ, ðoʊ ðə ʃeɪm kʌɾ ɪm kinli. ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə blʌd tə ɹɪzɔɹt tə ði izi weɪ tə ɪskeɪp dɪsɡɹeɪs; ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd fɔt tə ðə læst. mjuzənʒ kəmændəɾ əɹ pɝsənəl bɑɾiɡɑɹd, bʌɾ əz ðə haɪɛstʃɹæŋkɪŋ mɛmbɝ ə ðə ɡɑɹd ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, ɪt wɑz kɛɹidz duɾi tə ɹɪtɝn əɹ seɪfli. ɛvɹi kɹæni ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɑz biɪŋ sɝtʃt ɑn wʌn ɪkskjus əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɛvɹi vɛsəl lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə ɹoʊboʊt, bʌt moʊst ɔfən baɪ mɛn ɪɡnɝən ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ, ʌnəwɛɹ ðət ðə feɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪtɝn maɪt ɹɛst ɑn ðɛɹ dɪlədʒəns. ðə duɾi wɑz hɪz. ʌv kɔɹs, ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli wɑz ɡɪvən tə ivən mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ɪntʃɹiɡz ðən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə blʌd, ən ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn fɹikwənli pleɪɾ ə vɛɹi dip ɡeɪm ɪndid, wɪð ə ʃɑɹp ən dɛdli skɪl. oʊnli ə fju wɝ əwɛɹ ðət ʃi hæd vænɪʃt twaɪs bɪfɔɹ, ən hæd bɪn ɹipɔɹɾəd dɛd, tə ðə vɛɹi ɝeɪnʒmənt ə hɝ fjunɝəl ɹaɪts, ɔl baɪ hɝ oʊn kɑntʃɹaɪvɪŋ. wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizənz fəɹ əɹ dɪsəpɪɹəns, ðoʊ, hi hæd tə faɪn ən pɹətɛk hɝ. soʊ fɑɹ i hæd noʊ klu haʊ. swɑloʊd baɪ ðə stɔɹm. əɹ pɝhæps baɪ ðə leɪɾi ʌv ðə ʃædoʊz. ðəɹ hæd bɪn kaʊnləs ətɛmps tə kɪdnæp əɹ əsæsəneɪt hɝ, bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɑn ðə deɪ ʌv əɹ bɝθ. ɪf i faʊn əɹ dɛd, hi mʌs faɪn u hæd kɪl hɝ, hu hæd ɡɪvən ði ʌltəmət kəmænz, ən əvɛnʒ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst. ðət wɑz ɪz duɾi, tu.

With their own lives, when necessary, and willingly given. And nine nights past, the High Lady Tuon had vanished as if swallowed by the storm. He did not think of her as the Daughter of the Nine Moons, could not until he knew she was no longer under the veil. He had not considered taking his own life, either, though the shame cut him keenly. It was for the Blood to resort to the easy way to escape disgrace; the Deathwatch Guard fought to the last. Musenge commanded her personal bodyguard, but as the highestranking member of the Guard this side of the Aryth Ocean, it was Karede's duty to return her safely. Every cranny in the city was being searched on one excuse or another, every vessel larger than a rowboat, but most often by men ignorant of what they were searching for, unaware that the fate of the Return might rest on their diligence. The duty was his. Of course, the Imperial family was given to even more complicated intrigues than the rest of the Blood, and the High Lady Tuon frequently played a very deep game indeed, with a sharp and deadly skill. Only a few were aware that she had vanished twice before, and had been reported dead, to the very arrangement of her funeral rites, all by her own contriving. Whatever the reasons for her disappearance, though, he had to find and protect her. So far he had no clue how. Swallowed by the storm. Or perhaps by the Lady of the Shadows. There had been countless attempts to kidnap or assassinate her, beginning on the day of her birth. If he found her dead, he must find who had killed her, who had given the ultimate commands, and avenge her whatever the cost. That was his duty, too.

ə slɛndɝ mæn slɪpt ɪndə ðə ɹum fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪ wɪθaʊt nɑkɪŋ. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn wʌn ə ði ɪnz steɪbəlmən fɹəm ɪz ɹʌf koʊt, bʌt noʊ loʊkəl hæɾ ɪz peɪl hɛɹ əɹ ðə blu aɪz ðət slɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum əz ðoʊ mɛmɝaɪzɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪt. hɪz hæn slɪpt ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, ən kɛɹid ɹihɝs tu weɪz ə kɪlɪŋ ɪm bɛɹ-hændəɾ ɪn ðə bɹif moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i pɹədust ə smɔl, ɡoʊld-bɔɹɾɝd aɪvɝi plæk wɝkt wɪð ðə ɹeɪvən ən ðə taʊɝ. sikɝz fəɹ tʃɹuθ dɪd nɑɾ əv tə nɑk.

A slender man slipped into the room from the hallway without knocking. He might have been one of the inn's stablemen from his rough coat, but no local had his pale hair or the blue eyes that slid across the room as though memorizing everything in it. His hand slipped under his coat, and Karede rehearsed two ways of killing him bare-handed in the brief moment before he produced a small, gold-bordered ivory plaque worked with the Raven and the Tower. Seekers for Truth did not have to knock.

kɪlɪŋ əm wɑz fɹaʊn əpɑn.

Killing them was frowned upon.

"liv ʌs," ðə sikɝ toʊld ædʒɪmbʊɹə, tʌkɪŋ əweɪ ðə plæk wʌns i wɑz ʃʊɹ kɛɹid hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt. ðə lɪɾəl mæn ɹɪmeɪn kɹaʊtʃt ɑn ɪz hilz, moʊʃənləs, ən ðə sikɝz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ivən ɪn ðə kɛnsɑɾə hɪlz ɛvɹiwʌn nu ə sikɝz wɝd wɑz lɔ. wɛl, pɝhæps nɑɾ ɪn səm ə ðə mɔɹ ɹɪmoʊt hɪl fɔɹts, nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪ bɪliv noʊ wʌn nu ðə sikɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ædʒɪmbʊɹə nu bɛɾɝ ðən ðɪs.

"Leave us," the Seeker told Ajimbura, tucking away the plaque once he was sure Karede had recognized it. The little man remained crouched on his heels, motionless, and the Seeker's eyebrows rose in surprise. Even in the Kaensada Hills everyone knew a Seeker's word was law. Well, perhaps not in some of the more remote hill forts, not if they believed no one knew the Seeker was there, but Ajimbura knew better than this.

"weɪɾ aʊtsaɪd," kɛɹid kəmændəd ʃɑɹpli, ən ædʒɪmbʊɹə ɹoʊz wɪð əlækɹəɾi, mɝmɝɪŋ, "aɪ hɪɹ ən oʊbeɪ, haɪ wʌn." hi stʌɾid ðə sikɝ oʊpənli, ðoʊ, əz ɪf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə sikɝ nu hi hæd mɑɹkt ɪz feɪs, bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə ɹum. hi wɑz gɑnə ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf bɪhɛɾɪd, wʌn deɪ.

"Wait outside," Karede commanded sharply, and Ajimbura rose with alacrity, murmuring, "I hear and obey, high one." He studied the Seeker openly, though, as if to make sure the Seeker knew he had marked his face, before leaving the room. He was going to get himself beheaded, one day.

"ə pɹɛʃəs θɪŋ, lɔɪəlti," ðə peɪl-hɛɹd mæn sɛd, aɪɪŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp, æftɝ ædʒɪmbʊɹə pʊl ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɪmsɛlf. "ju ɑɹ ɪnvɑlvd ɪn lɔɹd julənz plænz, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl kɛɹid? aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðæt." kɛɹid muv tu bɹɑnz mæp-weɪts ʃeɪp laɪk laɪənz ən lɛt ðə mæp ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɹoʊl ʌp ɑn ɪtsɛlf. ði ʌðɝ hæd nɑt bɪn ənɹoʊld, jɛt. "ju mʌst æsk lɔɹd julən, sikɝ. lɔɪəlti tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn ɪz pɹɛʃəs əbʌv ðə bɹɛθ ə laɪf, fɑloʊd kloʊsli baɪ noʊɪŋ wən tə kip saɪlənt. ðə mɔɹ u spik ʌv ə θɪŋ, ðə mɔɹ wɪl lɝn ʌv ɪɾ u ʃəd nɑt." noʊ wʌn ʃɔɹɾ ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli ɹɪbjukt ə sikɝ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ hænd ɡaɪɾəd hɪm, bʌt ðə fɛloʊ əpɪɹɾ ʌnəfɛktɪd. ðən əɡɛn, hi siɾəd hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə ɹumz kʊʃən ɑɹmtʃɛɹ ən meɪɾ ə tɛn ə hɪz ɹɪŋɝz, piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ əm ət kɛɹid, hu hæd ðə tʃɔɪs ə muvɪŋ ɪz oʊn tʃɛɹ əɹ livɪŋ ðə mæn ɔlmoʊst əɾ ɪz bæk. moʊs pipəl wʊɾə bɪn vɛɹi nɝvəs əbaʊt hævɪŋ ə sikɝ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. moʊst wʊɾə bɪn nɝvəs hævɪŋ ə sikɝ ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum. kɛɹid hɪɾ ə smaɪl ən dɪd nɑt muv. hi hæɾ oʊnli tə tɝn ɪz hɛɾ ə fɹækʃən, ən i wɑz tʃɹeɪn ət siɪŋ klɪɹli wʌt leɪ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝz ə saɪt.

"A precious thing, loyalty," the pale-haired man said, eyeing the tabletop, after Ajimbura pulled the door shut behind himself. "You are involved in Lord Yulan's plans, Banner-General Karede? I would not have expected the Deathwatch Guard to be part of that." Karede moved two bronze map-weights shaped like lions and let the map of Tar Valon roll up on itself. The other had not been unrolled, yet. "You must ask Lord Yulan, Seeker. Loyalty to the Crystal Throne is precious above the breath of life, followed closely by knowing when to keep silent. The more who speak of a thing, the more will learn of it who should not." No one short of the Imperial family rebuked a Seeker or whatever Hand guided him, but the fellow appeared unaffected. Then again, he seated himself in the room's cushioned armchair and made a tent of his ringers, peering over them at Karede, who had the choice of moving his own chair or leaving the man almost at his back. Most people would have been very nervous about having a Seeker behind them. Most would have been nervous having a Seeker in the same room. Karede hid a smile and did not move. He had only to turn his head a fraction, and he was trained at seeing clearly what lay in the corners of sight.

"ju mʌs bi pɹaʊɾ ə jəɹ sʌnz," ðə sikɝ sɛd, "tu fɑloʊɪŋ jə ɪndə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd, ðə θɝd lɪstəɾ əmʌŋ ði ɑnɝd dɛd. jəɹ waɪf wʊɾə bɪn vɛɹi pɹaʊd." "wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm, sikɝ?" ði ænsɝɪŋ saɪləns wɑz dɛfənɪŋ. mɔɹ pipəl ɹɪbjuk sikɝz ðən ɪnkwaɪɝɾ æftɝ ðɛɹ neɪmz.

"You must be proud of your sons," the Seeker said, "two following you into the Deathwatch Guard, the third listed among the honored dead. Your wife would have been very proud." "What is your name, Seeker?" The answering silence was deafening. More people rebuked Seekers than inquired after their names.

"mɔɹ," ðə ɹɪplaɪ keɪm faɪnəli. "ælmjɝɹɑt mɔɹ." soʊ. mɔɹ. hi hæɾ ən ænsɛstɝ u hæd kʌm wɪð luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ, ðɛn, ən wɑz ɹaɪtli pɹaʊd. wɪθaʊɾ æksɛs tə ðə bɹiɾɪŋ bʊks, wɪtʃ noʊ dækoʊvæl wɑz əlaʊd, kɛɹid hæd noʊ weɪ ʌv noʊɪŋ wɛðɝ ɛni ʌv ðə teɪlz əbaʊɾ ɪz oʊn ænsɛstʃɹi wɝ tʃɹu - hi ɔlsoʊ maɪɾ əv ən ænsɛstɝ u hæd wʌns fɑloʊd ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔkwɪŋ - bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. mɛn u tʃɹaɪd tə stæn ɑn ðɛɹ fɔɹbɛɹz' ʃoʊldɝz ɹæðɝ ðən ðɛɹ oʊn fiɾ ɔfən faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz ʃɔɹɾɝ baɪ ə hɛd. ɪspɛʃli dækoʊvæl.

"Mor," the reply came finally. "Almurat Mor." So. Mor. He had an ancestor who had come with Luthair Paendrag, then, and was rightly proud. Without access to the breeding books, which no da'covale was allowed, Karede had no way of knowing whether any of the tales about his own ancestry were true - he also might have an ancestor who had once followed the great Hawkwing - but it did not matter. Men who tried to stand on their forebears' shoulders rather than their own feet often found themselves shorter by a head. Especially da'covale.

"kɔl mi fɹɪk. wəɹ boʊθ ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn. wʌt dʒju wɑn ə mi, ælmjɝɹɑt? nɑt tə dɪskʌs maɪ fæmli, aɪ θɪŋk." ɪf ɪz sʌnz wɝ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl, ðə fɛloʊ wəd nɛvɝ əv mɛnʃən əm soʊ sun, ən kɑliə wɑz bɪɑn ɛni mɪzɝi. fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, kɛɹid kəd si ðə stʃɹʌɡəl ɑn ðə sikɝz feɪs, ðoʊ hi hɪɾ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst wɛl ɪnʌf. ðə mæn hæd lɔs kəntʃɹoʊl ə ði ɪntɝvju - əz i maɪɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd, flæʃɪŋ ɪz plæk əz ðoʊ ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd wɝ nɑt ɹɛɾi tə θɹʌst ə dæɡɝ ɪndə hɪz oʊn hɑɹɾ ɑn kəmænd.

"Call me Furyk. We are both the property of the Crystal Throne. What do you want of me, Almurat? Not to discuss my family, I think." If his sons were in trouble, the fellow would never have mentioned them so soon, and Kalia was beyond any misery. From the corner of his eye, Karede could see the struggle on the Seeker's face, though he hid it almost well enough. The man had lost control of the interview - as he might have expected, flashing his plaque as though a Deathwatch Guard were not ready to thrust a dagger into his own heart on command.

"lɪsən tə ə stɔɹi," mɔɹ sɛd sloʊli, "æn tɛl mi wʌt jə θɪŋk." hɪz ɡeɪz wɑz fæsən tə kɛɹiɾ əz ɪf baɪ tæks, stʌɾiɪŋ, weɪɪŋ, ɪvæljueɪɾɪŋ əz ðoʊ kɛɹid wɝ ɑn ðə blɑk ət seɪl. "ðɪs keɪm tə əs ɪn ðə læs fju deɪz." baɪ ʌs, hi mɛn ðə sikɝz. "ɪt bɪɡæn əmʌŋ ðə loʊkəl pipəl, əz nɪɹ əz wi kən tɛl, ðoʊ wɪv nɑt jɛt faʊn ði ɝɪdʒənəl sɔɹs. səpoʊzədli, ə ɡɝl wɪð ə sindɑɹ æksɛn əz bɪn ɪkstɔɹɾɪŋ ɡoʊld ən dʒuəlɹi fɹəm mɝtʃəns hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ðə taɪɾəl dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz wɑz mɛnʃənd." hi ɡɹɪməst wɪð dɪsɡʌst, ən fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɪz fɪŋɡɝtɪps tɝnd waɪt, ðeɪ wɝ pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ soʊ hɑɹd. "nʌn ə ðə loʊkəlz sim tə ʌndɝstænd wʌt ðət taɪɾəl minz, bʌt ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən ə ðə ɡɝl ɪz ɹɪmɑɹkəbli pɹɪsaɪs. ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ækjɝət. ən noʊ wʌn kən ɹikɔl hɪɹɪŋ ðɪs ɹumɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə naɪɾ æftɝ . . . ðə naɪɾ æftɝ taɪlɪnz mɝɾɝ wɑz dɪskʌvɝd," hi fɪnɪʃt, tʃuzɪŋ ðə list ənplɛzən ɪvɛn tə fɪks ðə taɪm.

"Listen to a story," Mor said slowly, "and tell me what you think." His gaze was fastened to Karede as if by tacks, studying, weighing, evaluating as though Karede were on the block at sale. "This came to us in the last few days." By us, he meant the Seekers. "It began among the local people, as near as we can tell, though we have not yet found the original source. Supposedly, a girl with a Seandar accent has been extorting gold and jewelry from merchants here in Ebou Dar. The title Daughter of the Nine Moons was mentioned." He grimaced with disgust, and for a moment, his fingertips turned white, they were pressing against each other so hard. "None of the locals seem to understand what that title means, but the description of the girl is remarkably precise. Remarkably accurate. And no one can recall hearing this rumor before the night after . . . the night after Tylin's murder was discovered," he finished, choosing the least unpleasant event to fix the time.

"eɪ sindɑɹ æksɛnt," kɛɹid sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs, ən mɔɹ nɑɾəd. "ðɪs ɹumɝ əz pæs tə əɹ oʊn pipəl." ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən, bʌt mɔɹ nɑɾəd əɡɛn. eɪ sindɑɹ æksɛn ən ən ækjɝət dɪskɹɪpʃən, tu θɪŋz noʊ loʊkəl kəɾ ɪnvɛnt. sʌmwʌn wɑz pleɪɪŋ ə vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs ɡeɪm. deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz, ən fəɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ. "haʊ dʌz ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs teɪk ɹisən ɪvɛns?" ðəɹ wəd bi lɪsənɝz əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns, laɪkli əmʌŋ ivən ði ɛbu dɑɹi sɝvəns baɪ naʊ, ən wʌt ðə lɪsənɝz hɝd sun pæs tə ðə sikɝz.

"A Seandar accent," Karede said in a flat voice, and Mor nodded. "This rumor has passed to our own people." That was not a question, but Mor nodded again. A Seandar accent and an accurate description, two things no local could invent. Someone was playing a very dangerous game. Dangerous for themselves, and for the Empire. "How does the Tarasin Palace take recent events?" There would be Listeners among the servants, likely among even the Ebou Dari servants by now, and what the Listeners heard soon passed to the Seekers.

mɔɹ ʌndɝstʊd ðə kwɛstʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə mɛnʃən wʌt ʃəd nɑt bi mɛnʃənd. hi ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ən ɪndɪfɹən toʊn. "ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz ɑntʊɹɑʒ kæɹiz ɑn əz ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ əz hæpənd, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ænæθ, hɝ tʃɹuθ spikɝ, hæz teɪkən tə sɪkluʒən, bʌɾ aɪm toʊl ðəɾ ɪz nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl fəɹ hɝ. sjuɹɔθ hɝsɛlf ɪz ivən mɔɹ dɪstʃɹɔɾ ɪn pɹaɪvət ðən ɪn pʌblɪk. ʃi slips pʊɹli, snæps əɾ əɹ feɪvɹɪts, ən əz əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi biɾən oʊvɝ tʃɹaɪfəlz. ʃi ɔɹɾɝd ðə dɛθ ʌv wʌn sikɝ itʃ deɪ əntɪl mæɾɝz ɑɹ ɹɛktəfaɪd, ən oʊnli ɹɪsɪndɪd ði ɔɹɾɝ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi maɪt ɹʌn aʊɾ ə sikɝz bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹæn aʊɾ ə deɪz." hɪz ʃoʊldɝz muvd ɪn ə smɔl ʃɹʌɡ, pɝhæps tə ɪndəkeɪt ðɪs wɑz ɔl ɪn ə deɪ fəɹ sikɝz, pɝhæps ɪn ɹɪlif əɾ ə nɪɹ ɪskeɪp. "ɪts ʌndɝstændəbəl. ɪf ʃiz kɔl tə əkaʊnt, ʃɪl pɹeɪ fəɹ ðə dɛθ ə tɛn θaʊzən tɛɹz. ði ʌðɝ blʌɾ u noʊ wʌɾ əz hæpən ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɹoʊ aɪz ɪn ðə bæks ə ðɛɹ hɛdz. ə fju hæv ivən kwaɪətli meɪd fjunɝəl ɝeɪnʒmənts, tə kʌvɝ ɛni əvɛntʃuælɪɾi."

Mor understood the question, of course. There was no need to mention what should not be mentioned. He replied in an indifferent tone. "The High Lady Tuon's entourage carries on as though nothing has happened, except that Anath, her Truth Speaker, has taken to seclusion, but I am told that is not unusual for her. Suroth herself is even more distraught in private than in public. She sleeps poorly, snaps at her favorites, and has her property beaten over trifles. She ordered the death of one Seeker each day until matters are rectified, and only rescinded the order this morning, when she realized she might run out of Seekers before she ran out of days." His shoulders moved in a small shrug, perhaps to indicate this was all in a day for Seekers, perhaps in relief at a near escape. "It's understandable. If she is called to account, she will pray for the Death of Ten Thousand Tears. The other Blood who know what has happened are trying to grow eyes in the backs of their heads. A few have even quietly made funeral arrangements, to cover any eventuality."

kɛɹid wɑntəɾ ə klɪɹɝ lʊk ət ðə mænz feɪs. hi wɑz ɪnjʊɹd tə ɪnsʌlt - ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - bʌt ðɪs. . . . pʊʃɪŋ bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ, hi stʊɾ ən sæɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. mɔɹ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ənblɪŋkɪŋ, tɛns tə dɪfɛn əɡɛnst ən ətæk, ən kɛɹid dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ tə stɪl ɪz æŋɡɝ. "waɪ dɪd jə kʌm tə mi ɪf jə bɪliv ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ɑɹ ɪmplɪkeɪɾɪd ɪn ðɪs?" ði ɛfɝɾ ə kipɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs lɛvəl ɔlmoʊst stʃɹæŋɡəl hɪm. sɪns ðə fɝs dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz swɔɹ ɑn ðə kɔɹps ə luthɛɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ tə dɪfɛn ɪz sʌn, ðəɹ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tʃɹizən əmʌŋ ðə ɡɑɹdz! nɛvɝ!

Karede wanted a clearer look at the man's face. He was inured to insult - that was part of the training - but this. . . . Pushing back his chair, he stood and sat at the edge of the writing table. Mor stared at him unblinking, tensed to defend against an attack, and Karede drew a deep breath to still his anger. "Why did you come to me if you believe the Deathwatch Guards are implicated in this?" The effort of keeping his voice level almost strangled him. Since the first Deathwatch Guards swore on the corpse of Luthair Paendrag to defend his son, there had never been treason among the Guards! Never!

mɔɹ ɹɪlæks baɪ ɪŋkɹəməns əz i ɹilaɪz ðət kɛɹid dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə kɪl hɪm, ət lis nɑt ɹaɪt ðɛn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə heɪz ə swɛɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɪt sɛɾ ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd kən si ə bʌɾɝflaɪz bɹɛθ. juv ɛniθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk?" kɛɹid dʒɛstʃɝd kɝtli tə ðə bɹɪk hɑɹθ, wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ kʌp ən pɪtʃɝ sæt nɪɹ ðə fleɪmz, tə kip wɔɹm. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, əntʌtʃt, sɪns ædʒɪmbʊɹə bɹɔɾ əm wən kɛɹiɾ əwoʊk. "ðə waɪn meɪ bi kul baɪ naʊ, bʌt bi fɹi ʌv ɪt. ən wən jəɹ θɹoʊɾ ɪz wɛt, jəl ænsɝ maɪ kwɛstʃən. iðɝ jə səspɛkt ɡɑɹdzmɪn, əɹ jə wɪʃ tə pleɪ mi ɪn səm ɡeɪm ə jəɹ oʊn, ən baɪ maɪ aɪz, əl noʊ wɪtʃ, ən waɪ." ðə fɛloʊ saɪɾəld tə ðə hɑɹθ, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, bʌɾ əz mɔɹ bɛn fəɹ ðə pɪtʃɝ, hi fɹaʊn ən ðən ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹt. wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə sɪlvɝ-ɹɪm boʊl wɪð ə ɹæmʃɹn-pæɾɝnd sɪlvɝ beɪs sæt bɪsaɪd ðə kʌp. laɪɾ ə hɛvən, ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd bɪn toʊld ɔfən ɪnʌf tə kip ðət θɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪt! ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊt ðət mɔɹ ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt fəɹ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz.

Mor relaxed by increments as he realized that Karede did not intend to kill him, at least not right then, but there was a haze of sweat on his forehead. "I have heard it said a Deathwatch Guard can see a butterfly's breath. Do you have anything to drink?" Karede gestured curtly to the brick hearth, where a silver cup and pitcher sat near the flames, to keep warm. They had been there, untouched, since Ajimbura brought them when Karede awoke. "The wine may be cool by now, but be free of it. And when your throat is wet, you will answer my question. Either you suspect Guardsmen, or you wish to play me in some game of your own, and by my eyes, I will know which, and why." The fellow sidled to the hearth, watching him from the corner of his eye, but as Mor bent for the pitcher, he frowned and then gave a small start. What appeared to be a silver-rimmed bowl with a ram'shorn-patterned silver base sat beside the cup. Light of heaven, Ajimbura had been told often enough to keep that thing out of sight! There was no doubt that Mor recognized it for what it was.

ðə mæn kənsɪɾɝd tʃɹizən pɑsəbəl fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz? "pɔɹ fəɹ mi əz wɛl, ɪf jə wɪl." mɔɹ blɪŋkt, ʃoʊɪŋ ə feɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən - hi hɛl ði oʊnli ɑbviəs kʌp - ən ðən ə laɪɾ ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. ən ənizi laɪt. hi fɪl ðə boʊl, tu, ə tʃɹaɪfəl ənstɛɾəli, ən waɪpt ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz koʊt bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp. ɛvɹi mæn hæɾ ɪz lɪməts, ivən ə sikɝ, ən ə mæn pʊʃt tə ðɛm wɑz ɪspɛʃli deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɔf bæləns.

The man considered treason possible for the Guards? "Pour for me as well, if you will." Mor blinked, showing a faint consternation - he held the only obvious cup - and then a light of understanding appeared in his eyes. An uneasy light. He filled the bowl, too, a trifle unsteadily, and wiped his hand on his coat before taking it up. Every man had his limits, even a Seeker, and a man pushed to them was especially dangerous, but he was also off balance.

æksɛptɪŋ ðə skʌl-kʌp wɪð boʊθ hænz, kɛɹid ɹeɪzd ɪt haɪ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz hɛd. "tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ ɪn ɑnɝ ən ɡlɔɹi. dɛθ ən ʃeɪm tə hɝ ɛnəmiz."

Accepting the skull-cup with both hands, Karede raised it high and lowered his head. "To the Empress, may she live forever in honor and glory. Death and shame to her enemies."

"tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ ɪn ɑnɝ ən ɡlɔɹi," mɔɹ ɛkoʊd, boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən lɪftɪŋ ɪz kʌp. "dɛθ ən ʃeɪm tə hɝ ɛnəmiz."

"To the Empress, may she live forever in honor and glory," Mor echoed, bowing his head and lifting his cup. "Death and shame to her enemies."

pʊɾɪŋ ædʒɪmbʊɹəz kʌp tə hɪz lɪps, kɛɹid wɑz əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝ mæn wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm dʒɹɪŋk. ðə waɪn wɑz ɪndid kul, ðə spaɪsəz bɪɾɝ, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪnt, ækɹɪd hɪn ə sɪlvɝ pɑlɪʃ; hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðə teɪst ə dɛd mænz dʌst wɑz ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. mɔɹ dæʃt ɔf hæf ɪz oʊn waɪn ɪn hɝid ɡʌlps, ðən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz kʌp, sim tə ɹilaɪz wʌɾ i hæd dʌn, ən meɪɾ ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt tə ɹɪɡeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɪmsɛlf. "fɹɪk kɛɹid," hi sɛd bɹɪskli. "bɔɹn fɔɹɾi-tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ tə wivɝz, ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv wʌn dʒɑləd mɑɡoʊnaɪn, ə kɹæfsmən ɪn ænkɹɪd. tʃoʊzən ət fɪftin fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz. saɪɾəd twaɪs fəɹ hɛɹoʊɪzəm ən mɛnʃən ɪn dɪspætʃɪz θɹi taɪmz, ðɛn, əz ə sɛvən-jɪɹ vɛɾɝən, neɪm tə ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹd ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn əpɑn əɹ bɝθ." ðət hæd nɑt bɪn əɹ neɪm ðɛn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt mɛnʃənɪŋ əɹ bɝθ-neɪm wʊɾə bɪn ən ɪnsəlt. "ðæt seɪm jɪɹ, əz wʌn ə θɹi sɝvaɪvɝz ə ðə fɝs noʊn ətɛmpt ɑn əɹ laɪf, tʃoʊzən fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ əz ən ɔfəsɝ. sɝvəs dʊɹɪŋ ðə mʊaɪɑmi əpɹaɪzɪŋ ən ðə dʒiɑnmɪn ɪnsəɾənt, mɔɹ saɪteɪʃənz fəɹ hɛɹoʊɪzəm, mɔɹ mɛnʃənz ɪn dɪspætʃɪz, ən əsaɪnmən bæk tə ðə haɪ leɪɾiz bɑɾiɡɑɹd dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ əɹ fɝs tʃɹu-neɪm deɪ." mɔɹ pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz waɪn, ðən lʊkt ʌp sʌɾənli. "æt jəɹ ɹɪkwɛst. ənjuʒəwəl, ðæt. ðə fɑloʊɪŋ jɪɹ, jə tʊk θɹi sɪɹiəs wunz ʃildɪŋ əɹ wɪð jəɹ bɑɾi əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ʌv əsæsənz. ʃi ɡeɪv jə hɝ moʊs pɹɛʃəs pəzɛʃən, ə dɑl. æftɝ mɔɹ dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt sɝvəs, wɪð fɝðɝ saɪteɪʃənz ən mɛnʃənz, jə wɝ səlɛktəd fəɹ ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹd ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ən sɝv ðəɹ əntɪl neɪm tə əkʌmpəni ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk tə ðiz lænz wɪð ðə heɪlin. taɪmz tʃeɪnʒ, ən mɛn tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ gɑnə ɡɑɹd ðə θɹoʊn, jə meɪd tu ʌðɝ ɹɪkwɛsts fəɹ əsaɪnmən tə ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd. moʊst ənjuʒəwəl. ən jə kɛp ðə dɑl əntɪl ɪt wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt faɪɝ ə soʊhimə, ə mæɾɝ ɔfən jɪɹz."

Putting Ajimbura's cup to his lips, Karede was aware of the other man watching him drink. The wine was indeed cool, the spices bitter, and there was a faint, acrid hint of silver polish; he told himself the taste of dead man's dust was his imagination. Mor dashed off half his own wine in hurried gulps, then stared at his cup, seemed to realize what he had done, and made a visible effort to regain control of himself. "Furyk Karede," he said briskly. "Born forty-two years ago to weavers, the property of one Jalid Magonine, a craftsman in Ancarid. Chosen at fifteen for training in the Deathwatch Guards. Cited twice for heroism and mentioned in dispatches three times, then, as a seven-year veteran, named to the bodyguard of the High Lady Tuon upon her birth." That had not been her name then, of course, but mentioning her birth-name would have been an insult. "That same year, as one of three survivors of the first known attempt on her life, chosen for training as an officer. Service during the Muyami Uprising and the Jianmin Incident, more citations for heroism, more mentions in dispatches, and assignment back to the High Lady's bodyguard just before her first true-name day." Mor peered into his wine, then looked up suddenly. "At your request. Unusual, that. The following year, you took three serious wounds shielding her with your body against another set of assassins. She gave you her most precious possession, a doll. After more distinguished service, with further citations and mentions, you were selected for the bodyguard of the Empress herself, may she live forever, and served there until named to accompany the High Lord Turak to these lands with the Hailene. Times change, and men change, but before going to guard the throne, you made two other requests for assignment to the High Lady Tuon's bodyguard. Most unusual. And you kept the doll until it was destroyed in the Great Fire of Sohima, a matter often years."

nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, kɛɹid wɑz ɡlæɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ðəɾ əlaʊɾ ɪm tə meɪnteɪn ə smuð feɪs noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt. kɛɹləs ɪkspɹɛʃənz ɡeɪv əweɪ tu mʌtʃ tə ən əpoʊnənt. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə feɪs ə ðə smɔl ɡɝl u hæd leɪd ðət dɑl ɑn ɪz lɪɾɝ. hi kəd hɪɹ əɹ stɪl. juv pɹətɛktəd maɪ laɪf, soʊ jə mʌs teɪk ɛmɪlə tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ jə ɪn tɝn, ʃi sɛd. ʃi kæn ɹɪli pɹətɛk ju, ʌv kɔɹs; ʃiz oʊnli ə dɑl. bʌt kip əɹ tə ɹimaɪn jə ðəɾ əl ɔlweɪz hɪɹ ɪf jə spik maɪ neɪm. ɪf aɪm stɪl əlaɪv, ʌv kɔɹs.

Not for the first time, Karede was glad of the training that allowed him to maintain a smooth face no matter what. Careless expressions gave away too much to an opponent. He remembered the face of the small girl who had laid that doll on his litter. He could hear her still. You have protected my life, so you must take Emela to watch over you in turn, she said. She can't really protect you, of course; she's only a doll. But keep her to remind you that I will always hear if you speak my name. If I'm still alive, of course.

"maɪ ɑnɝ ɪz lɔɪəlti," hi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ædʒɪmbʊɹəz kʌp ɑn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl kɛɹfəli, soʊ əz nɑt tə slɑp waɪn ɑntu hɪz peɪpɝz. haʊɛvɝ ɔfən ðə fɛloʊ pɑlɪʃt ðə sɪlvɝ, kɛɹid dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i bɑðɝd tə wɑʃ ðə θɪŋ. "lɔɪəlti tə ðə θɹoʊn. waɪ dɪd jə kʌm tə mi?" mɔɹ muv slaɪtli, soʊ ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ wɑz bɪtwin ðɛm. noʊ daʊɾ i θɔɾ i wɑz stændɪŋ kæʒəwəli, bʌɾ i wɑz klɪɹli ɹɛɾi tə θɹoʊ ðə waɪnkʌp. hi hæɾ ə naɪf ʌndɝ ɪz koʊɾ ɪn ðə smɔl ə hɪz bæk, ən pɹɑbli ət list wʌn ʌðɝ. "θɹi ɹɪkwɛsts tə dʒɔɪn ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd. ən jə kɛp ðə dɑl." "ðæt mʌtʃ, aɪ ʌndɝstænd," kɛɹid toʊld ɪm dʒɹaɪli. ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ nɑt səpoʊz tə fɔɹm ətætʃməns tə ðoʊz ðeɪ wɝ sɛn tə ɡɑɹd. ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd sɝvd oʊnli ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, sɝv huɛvɝ səksiɾəd tə ðə θɹoʊn, wɪð ə hoʊl hɑɹɾ ən ə hoʊl feɪθ. bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət sɪɹiəs tʃaɪlz feɪs, ɔlɹɛɾi əwɛɹ ʃi maɪt nɑt lɪv tə də hɝ duɾi jɛt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə də ɪɾ ɛniweɪ, ən i hæd kɛp ðə dɑl. "bʌt ðɛɹz mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ɹumɝ ʌv ə ɡɝl, ɪzən ðɛɹ?"

"My honor is loyalty," he said, setting Ajimbura's cup on the writing table carefully, so as not to slop wine onto his papers. However often the fellow polished the silver, Karede did not think he bothered to wash the thing. "Loyalty to the throne. Why did you come to me?" Mor moved slightly, so the armchair was between them. No doubt he thought he was standing casually, but he was clearly ready to throw the winecup. He had a knife under his coat in the small of his back, and probably at least one other. "Three requests to join the High Lady Tuon's bodyguard. And you kept the doll." "That much, I understand," Karede told him dryly. The Guards were not supposed to form attachments to those they were sent to guard. The Deathwatch Guard served only the Crystal Throne, served whoever succeeded to the throne, with a whole heart and a whole faith. But he remembered that serious child's face, already aware she might not live to do her duty yet trying to do it anyway, and he had kept the doll. "But there's more to it than rumor of a girl, isn't there?"

"ə bʌɾɝflaɪz bɹɛθ," ðə fɛloʊ mɝmɝd. "ɪɾ ɪz ə plɛʒɝ tə tɔk tə sʌmwʌn u siz dipli. ɑn ðə naɪt ðət taɪlɪn wɑz mɝɾɝd, tu deɪmeɪn wɝ teɪkən fɹəm ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs kɛnəlz.

"A butterfly's breath," the fellow murmured. "It is a pleasure to talk to someone who sees deeply. On the night that Tylin was murdered, two damane were taken from the Tarasin Palace kennels.

boʊθ wɝ fɔɹmɝli ɛɛs sədaɪ. dʒju nɑt faɪn ðə koʊɪnsɪɾəns tu mʌtʃ?"

Both were formerly Aes Sedai. Do you not find the coincidence too much?"

"aɪ faɪn ɛni koʊɪnsɪɾəns səspɛkt, ælmjɝɹɑt. bʌt wʌɾ əz ðət tə də wɪð ɹumɝz ən . . . ʌðɝ mæɾɝz?"

"I find any coincidence suspect, Almurat. But what has that to do with rumors and . . . other matters?"

"ðɪs wɛb ɪz mɔɹ tæŋɡəl ðən jə ɪmædʒən. sɛvɹəl ʌðɝz lɛf ðə pæləs ðət naɪt, əmʌŋ əm ə jʌŋ mæn u wɑz əpɛɹənli taɪlɪnz pɛt, fɔɹ mɛn u wɝ sɝɾənli soʊlʒɝz, ən ən oʊldɝ mæn, wʌn tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, əɹ soʊ hi kɔl hɪmsɛlf, hu wɑz səpoʊzədli ə sɝvənt, bʌɾ u dɪspleɪd mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɛdʒəkeɪʃən ðən wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd. ət wʌn taɪm əɹ ənʌðɝ, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl sin wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɝ ɪn ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ ɹikleɪmd ɪt." ɪntɛnt, ðə sikɝ lin fɔɹwɝd slaɪtli oʊvɝ ðə bæk ə ði ɑɹmtʃɛɹ. "pɝhæps taɪlɪn wɑz nɑt mɝɾɝd kəz ʃi swɔɹ fiəlti, bʌt kəz ʃi hæd lɝn ə θɪŋz ðət wɝ deɪnʒɝəs.

"This web is more tangled than you imagine. Several others left the palace that night, among them a young man who was apparently Tylin's pet, four men who were certainly soldiers, and an older man, one Thom Merrilin, or so he called himself, who was supposedly a servant, but who displayed much more education than would be expected. At one time or another, they were all seen with Aes Sedai who were in the city before the Empire reclaimed it." Intent, the Seeker leaned forward slightly over the back of the armchair. "Perhaps Tylin was not murdered because she swore fealty, but because she had learned of things that were dangerous.

ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn kɛɹləs ɪn wʌt ʃi ɹɪvil tə ðə bɔɪ ɑn ðə pɪloʊz, ən i kæɹid wɝd tə mɛɹɪlɪn. wi kən kɔl ɪm ðəɾ əntɪl wi lɝn ə bɛɾɝ neɪm. ðə mɔɹ aɪ lɝn ə ðət wʌn, ðə mɔɹ ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ i ɪz: nɑlədʒəbəl ə ðə wɝld, wɛl-spoʊkən, əɾ iz wɪð noʊbəlz ən kɹaʊnz. ə kɔɹɾiɝ, ɪn fækt, ɪf jə dɪdnt noʊ hi wɑz ə sɝvənt. ɪf ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd sɝɾən plænz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðeɪ maɪt sɛn sətʃ ə mæn tə kæɹi ðɛm aʊt." plænz. ənθɪŋkɪŋ, kɛɹid pɪkt ʌp ædʒɪmbʊɹəz kʌp ən ɔlmoʊs dʒɹæŋk bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. hi kəntɪnjud tə hoʊl ðə kʌp, ðoʊ, soʊ əz nɑt tə ɡɪv əweɪ hɪz tɝmɔɪl. ɛvɹiwʌn  - ðoʊz u nu, ɛniweɪ - wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz dɪsəpɪɹəns wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə kɑntɛs tə səksid ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. sətʃ wɑz laɪf ɪn ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli. ɪf ðə haɪ leɪɾi wɝ dɛd, æftɝ ɔl, ə nu ɛɹ mʌs bi neɪmd. ɪf ʃi wɝ dɛd. ən ɪf nɑt. . .

She might have been careless in what she revealed to the boy on the pillows, and he carried word to Merrilin. We can call him that until we learn a better name. The more I learn of that one, the more intriguing he is: knowledgeable of the world, well-spoken, at ease with nobles and crowns. A courtier, in fact, if you didn't know he was a servant. If the White Tower had certain plans in Ebou Dar, they might send such a man to carry them out." Plans. Unthinking, Karede picked up Ajimbura's cup and almost drank before he realized what he was doing. He continued to hold the cup, though, so as not to give away his turmoil. Everyone  - those who knew, anyway - was sure the High Lady Tuon's disappearance was part of the contest to succeed the Empress, might she live forever. Such was life in the Imperial family. If the High Lady were dead, after all, a new heir must be named. If she were dead. And if not. . .

. ðə waɪt taʊɝ wʊɾə sɛn ðɛɹ bɛst, ɪf ðeɪ plæn tə kæɹi hɝ əweɪ. ɪf ðə sikɝ wɑz nɑt pleɪɪŋ ɪm ɪn səm ɡeɪm ə hɪz oʊn. sikɝz kəd tʃɹaɪ tə snɛɹ ɛniwʌn ʃɔɹɾ ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. "ju hæv teɪkən ðɪs noʊʃən tə jəɹ supɪɹiɝz, ən ðeɪ ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ɪt, əɹ jə wəd nɑt kʌm tə mi. ðæt, ɔɹ. . . . jə hævən mɛnʃən ɪt tə ðɛm, hæv ju? waɪ nɑt?"

. The White Tower would have sent their best, if they planned to carry her away. If the Seeker was not playing him in some game of his own. Seekers could try to snare anyone short of the Empress herself, might she live forever. "You have taken this notion to your superiors, and they rejected it, or you would not come to me. That, or. . . . You haven't mentioned it to them, have you? Why not?"

"mʌtʃ mɔɹ tæŋɡəl ðən jə kən ɪmædʒən," mɔɹ sɛd sɔfli, aɪɪŋ ðə dɔɹ əz ɪf səspɛktɪŋ ivzdʒɹɑpɝz. waɪ dɪɾ i ɡɹoʊ kɔʃəs naʊ? "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni . . . kɑmpləkeɪʃənz. ðə tu deɪmeɪn wɝ ɹimuv baɪ ðə leɪɾi ɛdʒiənɪn tæmɝəθ, hu hæz hæd dilɪŋz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪfɔɹ. kloʊs dilɪŋz, ɪn fækt. vɛɹi kloʊs. klɪɹli, ʃi ɹilis ði ʌðɝ deɪmeɪn tə kʌvɝ əɹ ɪskeɪp. ɛdʒiənɪn lɛf ðə sɪɾi ðət seɪm naɪt, wɪð θɹi deɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ, ən ɔlsoʊ, wi bɪliv, mɛɹɪlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz.

"Much more tangled than you can imagine," Mor said softly, eyeing the door as if suspecting eavesdroppers. Why did he grow cautious now? "There are many . . . complications. The two damane were removed by the Lady Egeanin Tamarath, who has had dealings with Aes Sedai before. Close dealings, in fact. Very close. Clearly, she released the other damane to cover her escape. Egeanin left the city that same night, with three damane in her entourage, and also, we believe, Merrilin and the others.

wi doʊnt noʊ hu ðə θɝd deɪmeɪn wɑz - wi səspɛk sʌmwʌn ɪmpɔɹɾənt əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ, əɹ pɝhæps ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɑz haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi - bʌt wɪv aɪdɛntəfaɪd ðə sʌldəm ʃi juzd, ən tu hæv kloʊs kənɛkʃənz wɪð sjuɹɔθ. hu hɝsɛlf əz mɛni kənɛkʃənz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ." fəɹ ɔl ɪz wɛɹinɪs, mɔɹ sɛd ðəɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ nɑɾ ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt. noʊ wʌndɝ i wɑz ɑn ɛdʒ.

We don't know who the third damane was - we suspect someone important among the Atha'an Miere, or perhaps an Aes Sedai who was hiding in the city - but we have identified the sul'dam she used, and two have close connections with Suroth. Who herself has many connections to Aes Sedai." For all his wariness, Mor said that as if it were not a lightning bolt. No wonder he was on edge.

soʊ. sjuɹɔθ plɑɾəd wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ən hæd kɝʌptɪɾ ət list səm ə ðə sikɝz əbʌv mɔɹ, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd pleɪs mɛn ʌndɝ wʌn ə ðɛɹ bɛs tə kæɹi aʊt sɝɾən ækʃənz. ɪt wɑz ɔl bəlivəbəl. wən kɛɹid wɑz sɛnt wɪð ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, hi hæd bɪn tæsk tə wɑtʃ ðə blʌd fəɹ oʊvɝ-æmbɪʃən. ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə pɑsəbɪləɾi, ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ðət ðeɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ tə sɛɾ ʌp ðɛɹ oʊn kɪŋdəmz. ən i hɪmsɛlf hæd sɛn mɛn ɪndə ə sɪɾi hi nu wəd fɔl wʌtɛvɝ wɑz dʌn tə dɪfɛn ɪt, soʊ ðeɪ kəd hɑɹm ði ɛnəmi fɹəm wɪðɪn.

So. Suroth plotted with Aes Sedai and had corrupted at least some of the Seekers above Mor, and the White Tower had placed men under one of their best to carry out certain actions. It was all believable. When Karede was sent with the Forerunners, he had been tasked to watch the Blood for over-ambition. There had always been a possibility, this far from the Empire, that they would try to set up their own kingdoms. And he himself had sent men into a city he knew would fall whatever was done to defend it, so they could harm the enemy from within.

"ju hæv ə dɝɛkʃən, ælmjɝɹɑt?"

"You have a direction, Almurat?"

mɔɹ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðeɪ wɛnt nɔɹθ, ən dʒəhænə wɑz mɛnʃən ɪn ðə pæləs steɪbəlz, bʌt ðət simz ən ɑbviəs ətɛmpt ət dɪsɛpʃən. ðəl əv tʃeɪnʒd dɝɛkʃən ət ðə fɝst ɑpɝtunəɾi.

Mor shook his head. "They went north, and Jehannah was mentioned in the palace stables, but that seems an obvious attempt at deception. They will have changed direction at the first opportunity.

wɪv tʃɛkt ɑn boʊts lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə hæv kæɹid ðə pɑɹɾi əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt vɛsəlz ə ðət saɪz kʌm ən ɡoʊ ɔl ðə taɪm. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, noʊ kəntʃɹoʊl." "ðɪs ɡɪvz mi ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə θɪŋk ɑn."

We have checked on boats large enough to have carried the party across the river, but vessels of that size come and go all the time. There is no order in this place, no control." "This gives me a great deal to think on."

ðə sikɝ ɡɹɪməst, ə slaɪt twɪstɪŋ ə hɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ i sim tə ɹilaɪz i hæd ɡɑɾən əz mʌtʃ kəmɪtmən əz kɛɹid wəd meɪk. hi nɑɾəd wʌns. "wʌtɛvɝ jə tʃuz tə du, jə ʃəd noʊ ðɪs. jə meɪ wʌndɝ haʊ ðə ɡɝl ɪkstɔɹɾɪd ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm ðiz mɝtʃəns. ɪt simz tu əɹ θɹi soʊlʒɝz ɔlweɪz əkʌmpənid hɝ. ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ wɑz ɔlsoʊ vɛɹi pɹɪsaɪs." hi hæf stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hæn əz ðoʊ tə tʌtʃ kɛɹidz ɹoʊb, bʌt waɪzli lɛɾ ɪt fɔl bæk tə hɪz saɪd. "moʊs pipəl kɔl ðət blæk. jə ʌndɝstæn mi? wʌtɛvɝ jə tʃuz tə du, də nɑt dɪleɪ." mɔɹ ɹeɪzd ɪz kʌp. "jɔɹ hɛlθ, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl. fɹɪk. jəɹ hɛlθ, ən ðə hɛlθ ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ." kɛɹid dʒɹeɪn ædʒɪmbʊɹəz kʌp wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. ðə sikɝ dɪpɑɹɾəd əz əbɹʌpli əz i hæɾ ɛntɝd, ən moʊməns æftɝ ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɪɾ oʊpən tə ədmɪɾ ædʒɪmbʊɹə. ðə lɪɾəl mæn stɛɹɾ əkjuzɪŋli ət ðə skʌl-kʌp ɪn kɛɹidz hænz.

The Seeker grimaced, a slight twisting of his mouth, but he seemed to realize he had gotten as much commitment as Karede would make. He nodded once. "Whatever you choose to do, you should know this. You may wonder how the girl extorted anything from these merchants. It seems two or three soldiers always accompanied her. The description of their armor was also very precise." He half stretched out a hand as though to touch Karede's robe, but wisely let it fall back to his side. "Most people call that black. You understand me? Whatever you choose to do, do not delay." Mor raised his cup. "Your health, Banner-General. Furyk. Your health, and the health of the Empire." Karede drained Ajimbura's cup without hesitation. The Seeker departed as abruptly as he had entered, and moments after the door closed behind him, it opened to admit Ajimbura. The little man stared accusingly at the skull-cup in Karede's hands.

"ju noʊ ðɪs ɹumɝ, ædʒɪmbʊɹə?" əz wɛl æsk wɛðɝ ðə sʌn ɹoʊz ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ əz æsk wɛðɝ ðə fɛloʊ hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt dɪnaɪ ɪt, ɪn ɛni keɪs.

"You know this rumor, Ajimbura?" As well ask whether the sun rose in the morning as ask whether the fellow had been listening. He did not deny it, in any case.

"aɪ wəd nɑt sɔɪl maɪ tʌŋ wɪð sətʃ fɪlθ, haɪ wʌn," hi sɛd, dʒɹɔɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp. kɛɹid pɝmɪɾəd hɪmsɛlf ə saɪ. wɛðɝ ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz dɪsəpɪɹəns wɑz əɹ oʊn duɪŋ əɹ səm ʌðɝz, ʃi wɑz ɪn ɡɹeɪt deɪnʒɝ. ən ɪf ðə ɹumɝ wɑz səm plɔɪ baɪ mɔɹ, ðə bɛst weɪ tə dɪfiɾ ənʌðɝz ɡeɪm wɑz tə meɪk ðə ɡeɪm jəɹ oʊn. "leɪ aʊt maɪ ɹeɪzɝ." sɪɾɪŋ daʊn, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz pɛn, hoʊldɪŋ ðə sliv ə hɪz ɹoʊb klɪɹ ə ði ɪŋk wɪð ɪz lɛf hænd. "ðɛn jəl faɪn kæptən mjuzənʒ, wən hiz əloʊn, ən ɡɪv ɪm ðɪs. ɹɪtɝn kwɪkli; əl əv mɔɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz fəɹ ju." ʃɔɹtli æftɝ nun ɑn ðə fɑloʊɪŋ deɪ, hi wɑz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə hɑɹbɝ ɑn ðə fɛɹi ðət dɪpɑɹɾəd itʃ aʊɝ, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə stʃɹɪkt ɹɪŋɪŋ ə bɛlz. ɪt wɑz ə lʌmbɝɪŋ bɑɹdʒ ðət hivd əz lɔŋ swips pɹəpɛld ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝz tʃɑpi sɝfəs. ðə ɹoʊps læʃɪŋ ə mɝtʃəns hæf-dʌzən kænvəs-kʌvɝd wæɡənz tə ðə klits ɑn ðə dɛk kɹikt wɪð ɛvɹi ʃɪft, ðə hɔɹsəz stæmp ðɛɹ hʊvz nɝvəsli, ən ði ɔɹsmɪn hæd tə fɛn ɔf wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz ən haɪɝd ɡɑɹdz u wɑntəd tə ɛmpti ðɛɹ bɛliz oʊvɝ ðə saɪd.

"I would not soil my tongue with such filth, high one," he said, drawing himself up. Karede permitted himself a sigh. Whether the High Lady Tuon's disappearance was her own doing or some other's, she was in great danger. And if the rumor was some ploy by Mor, the best way to defeat another's game was to make the game your own. "Lay out my razor." Sitting down, he reached for his pen, holding the sleeve of his robe clear of the ink with his left hand. "Then you will find Captain Musenge, when he is alone, and give him this. Return quickly; I will have more instructions for you." Shortly after noon on the following day, he was crossing the harbor on the ferry that departed each hour, according to the strict ringing of bells. It was a lumbering barge that heaved as long sweeps propelled it across the harbor's choppy surface. The ropes lashing a merchant's half-dozen canvas-covered wagons to the cleats on the deck creaked with every shift, the horses stamped their hooves nervously, and the oarsmen had to fend off wagon drivers and hired guards who wanted to empty their bellies over the side.

səm mɛn hæd noʊ stʌmək fəɹ ðə moʊʃən ʌv wɔɾɝ. ðə mɝtʃən hɝsɛlf, ə plʌmp-feɪst wʊmən wɪð ə kɑpɝi skɪn, stʊɾ ɪn ðə baʊ ɹæpt ɪn əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk, bælənsɪŋ izəli wɪð ðə fɛɹiz muvməns, stɛɹɪŋ fɪksədli ət ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ lændɪŋ ən ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ kɛɹid bɪsaɪd hɝ. ʃi maɪt noʊ ðəɾ i wɑz sintʃæn, fɹəm ðə sæɾəl ɑn ɪz beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls, bʌɾ ə pleɪn ɡɹeɪ kloʊk kʌvɝɾ ɪz ɹɛd-tʃɹɪmd ɡɹin koʊt, soʊ ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ə hɪm əɾ ɔl, ɪt wɑz əz ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi soʊlʒɝ. nɑɾ ə sɛɾəlɝ, wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp. ðəɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn ʃɑɹpɝ aɪz bæk ɪn ðə sɪɾi, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl i hæd dʌn tə ɪveɪd ðɛm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də əbaʊt ðæt. wɪð lʌk, hi hæɾ ə deɪ, pɝhæps tu, bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɹilaɪzd i wəd nɑt bi ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ði ɪn ɛni taɪm sun.

Some men had no stomach for the motion of water. The merchant herself, a plump-faced woman with a coppery skin, stood in the bow wrapped in her dark cloak, balancing easily with the ferry's movements, staring fixedly at the approaching landing and ignoring Karede beside her. She might know that he was Seanchan, from the saddle on his bay gelding if nothing else, but a plain gray cloak covered his red-trimmed green coat, so if she thought of him at all, it was as an ordinary soldier. Not a settler, with a sword on his hip. There might have been sharper eyes back in the city, despite all he had done to evade them, but there was nothing he could do about that. With luck, he had a day, perhaps two, before anyone realized he would not be returning to the inn any time soon.

swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl əz sun əz ðə fɛɹi bʌmp hɑɹɾ əɡɛns ðə lændɪŋ dɑks lɛðɝ-pæɾəd poʊsts, hi wɑz fɝst ɔf wən ðə loʊɾɪŋ ɡeɪt swʌŋ əsaɪd, ðə mɝtʃənt wɑz stɪl tʃɪviɪŋ əɹ dʒɹaɪvɝz tə ðə wæɡənz ən ðə fɛɹimən ənlæʃɪŋ wilz. hi kɛpt ɑldəzɑɹ tə ə sloʊ wɔk əkɹɔs ðə stoʊnz, stɪl slɪpɝi wɪð ðə mɔɹnɪŋz ɹeɪn, ə lɪɾɝ ə hɔɹs dʌŋ, ən ðə livɪŋz ʌv ə flɑk ə ʃip, ən lɛt ðə beɪz peɪs ɪnkɹis oʊnli wən i ɹitʃt ði ɪljən ɹoʊɾ ɪtsɛlf, ðoʊ hi kɛpt ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə tʃɹɑɾ ivən ðɛn. ɪmpeɪʃəns wɑz ə vaɪs wən bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə dʒɝni ʌv ənnoʊn lɛŋθ.

Swinging into his saddle as soon as the ferry bumped hard against the landing dock's leather-padded posts, he was first off when the loading gate swung aside, the merchant was still chivvying her drivers to the wagons and the ferrymen unlashing wheels. He kept Aldazar to a slow walk across the stones, still slippery with the morning's rain, a litter of horse dung, and the leavings of a flock of sheep, and let the bay's pace increase only when he reached the Illian Road itself, though he kept short of a trot even then. Impatience was a vice when beginning a journey of unknown length.

ɪnz laɪn ðə ɹoʊd bɪɑn ðə lændɪŋ, flæt-ɹuf bɪldɪŋz, kʌvɝɾ ɪn kɹækt ən fleɪkɪŋ waɪt plæstɝ ən wɪð feɪɾəd saɪnz aʊt fɹʌn əɹ nʌn əɾ ɔl. ðɪs ɹoʊd mɑɹk ðə nɔɹðɝn ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹæhəd, ən ɹʌfli dʒɹɛs mɛn slaʊtʃɪŋ ɑn bɛntʃɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪnz sʌlənli wɑtʃt ɪm pæs.

Inns lined the road beyond the landing, flat-roofed buildings, covered in cracked and flaking white plaster and with faded signs out front or none at all. This road marked the northern edge of the Rahad, and roughly dressed men slouching on benches in front of the inns sullenly watched him pass.

nɑt kəz i wɑz sintʃæn; hi səspɛktəd ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn noʊ bɹaɪɾɝ fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɑn hɔɹsbæk.

Not because he was Seanchan; he suspected they would have been no brighter for anyone on horseback.

ɛniwʌn u hæd tu kɔɪnz tə ɹʌb, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. sun i lɛft əm bɪhaɪnd, ðoʊ, ən ðə nɛks fju aʊɝz tʊk ɪm pæst ɑləv ɔɹtʃɝdz ən smɔl fɑɹmz wɛɹ ðə wɝkɝz wɝ əkʌstəmd ɪnʌf tə pæsɝzbi ɑn ðə ɹoʊd ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp fɹəm ðɛɹ leɪbɝz. ðə tʃɹæfɪk wɑz spɑɹs ɪn ɛni keɪs, ə hændfʊl ə haɪwil fɑɹmɝz' kɑɹts ən twaɪs ə mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn ɹʌmbəlɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɛbu dɑɹ, sɝaʊndəd baɪ haɪɝd ɡɑɹdz. mɛni ʌv ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz ən boʊθ mɝtʃəns wɔɹ ðoʊz dɪstɪŋktɪv ɪliɑnɝ bɪɹdz. ɪt sim stʃɹeɪnʒ ðəɾ ɪljən kəntɪnjud tə sɛn ɪts tʃɹeɪd tə ɛbu dɑɹ waɪl faɪɾɪŋ tə ɹɪzɪs ði ɛmpaɪɝ, bʌt pipəl ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði istɝn si wɝ ɔfən pəkjuljɝ, wɪð ɑd kʌstəmz, ən lɪɾəl laɪk ðə stɔɹiz toʊld ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hɔkwɪŋz hoʊmlænd. ɔfən nʌθɪŋ laɪk. ðeɪ mʌs bi ʌndɝstʊd, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə bi bɹɔɾ ɪndə ði ɛmpaɪɝ, bʌɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ wɑz fəɹ ʌðɝz, haɪɝ ðən hi. hi hæɾ ɪz duɾi.

Anyone who had two coins to rub, for that matter. Soon he left them behind, though, and the next few hours took him past olive orchards and small farms where the workers were accustomed enough to passersby on the road that they did not look up from their labors. The traffic was sparse in any case, a handful of highwheeled farmers' carts and twice a merchant's train rumbling toward Ebou Dar, surrounded by hired guards. Many of the drivers and both merchants wore those distinctive Illianer beards. It seemed strange that Illian continued to send its trade to Ebou Dar while fighting to resist the Empire, but people on this side of the Eastern Sea were often peculiar, with odd customs, and little like the stories told of the great Hawkwing's homeland. Often nothing like. They must be understood, of course, if they were to be brought into the Empire, but understanding was for others, higher than he. He had his duty.

ðə fɑɹmz ɡeɪv weɪ tə wʊdlænz ən filz ə skɹʌb, ən ɪz ʃædoʊ wɑz lɛŋθənɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ðə sʌn mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ tə ðə hɝaɪzən, baɪ ðə taɪm i sɔ wʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ. dʒʌst əhɛd, ædʒɪmbʊɹə wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðə nɔɹθ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd, pleɪɪŋ ə ɹid flut, ði ɪmədʒ ʌv ən aɪɾəlɝ ʃɝkɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ kɛɹid ɹitʃt hɪm, hi tʌk ðə flut bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt, ɡæðɝɾ ɪz bɹaʊn kloʊk ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə bɹʌʃ ən tʃɹiz. ɡlænsɪŋ bɪhaɪn tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə ɹoʊd wɑz ɛmpti ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən əz wɛl, kɛɹid tɝn ɑldəzɑɹ ɪndə ðə wʊdlæn ət ðə seɪm pɔɪnt. ðə lɪɾəl mæn wɑz weɪɾɪŋ dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd, əmʌŋ ə stæn ə səm sɔɹɾ ə lɑɹdʒ paɪn tʃɹi, ðə tɔlɪst izəli ə hʌnʒɹəd fit. hi meɪɾ ɪz hʌntʃ-ʃoʊldɝd baʊ ən skɹæmbəld ɪndə ðə sæɾəl ʌv ə lin tʃɛsnʌt wɪð fɔɹ waɪt fit.
