The farms gave way to woodlands and fields of scrub, and his shadow was lengthening in front of him, the sun more than halfway to the horizon, by the time he saw what he was looking for. Just ahead, Ajimbura was squatting on the north side of the road, playing a reed flute, the image of an idler shirking. Before Karede reached him, he tucked the flute behind his belt, gathered his brown cloak and vanished into the brush and trees. Glancing behind to make sure the road was empty in that direction as well, Karede turned Aldazar into the woodland at the same point. The little man was waiting just out of sight of the road, among a stand of some sort of large pine tree, the tallest easily a hundred feet. He made his hunch-shouldered bow and scrambled into the saddle of a lean chestnut with four white feet.

hi ɪnsɪstəd ðət waɪt fiɾ ɑn ə hɔɹs wɝ lʌki. "ðɪs weɪ, haɪ wʌn?" hi sɛd, ən ət kɛɹidz dʒɛstʃɝ ə pɝmɪʃən, tɝn ɪz maʊn dipɝ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst.

He insisted that white feet on a horse were lucky. "This way, high one?" he said, and at Karede's gesture of permission, turned his mount deeper into the forest.

ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt weɪ tə ɹaɪd, noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf ə maɪl, bʌt noʊ wʌn pæsɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd cʊɾə səspɛktəd wʌt weɪɾəd ðəɹ ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ. mjuzənʒ hæd bɹɔɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə ɡɑɹɾ ɑn ɡʊd hɔɹsəz ən twɛnti oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz, ɔl ɪn fʊl ɑɹmɝ, əlɔŋ wɪð pæk ænəməlz tə kæɹi səplaɪz fəɹ tu wiks. ðə pækhɔɹs ædʒɪmbʊɹə hæd bɹɔɾ aʊt jɛstɝdeɪ, wɪð kɛɹidz ɑɹmɝ, wəd bi əmʌŋ ðɛm. ə klʌstɝ ə sʌldəm wɝ stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ oʊn maʊns, səm pɛɾɪŋ ðə sɪks liʃt deɪmeɪn. wən mjuzənʒ ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd tə mit kɛɹid wɪð hɑɹɾə, ðə fɝst ɡɑɹɾənɝ, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡɹɪm-feɪs bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɪð ɪz ɡɹintəsɛld æks oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən, mɛlɪtin, ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑnz dɝsʌldəm, stɛpt ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl ən dʒɔɪn ðɛm.

They had only a short way to ride, no more than half a mile, but no one passing on the road could have suspected what waited there in a large clearing. Musenge had brought a hundred of the Guard on good horses and twenty Ogier Gardeners, all in full armor, along with pack animals to carry supplies for two weeks. The packhorse Ajimbura had brought out yesterday, with Karede's armor, would be among them. A cluster of sul'dam were standing beside their own mounts, some petting the six leashed damane. When Musenge rode forward to meet Karede with Hartha, the First Gardener, striding grim-faced beside him with his greentasseled axe over his shoulder. One of the women, Melitene, the High Lady Tuon's der'sul'dam, stepped into her saddle and joined them.

mjuzənʒ ən hɑɹɾə tʌtʃt fɪsts tə hɑɹt, ən kɛɹid ɹɪtɝn ðɛɹ səlut, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɛn tə ðə deɪmeɪn. tə wʌn ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ, ə smɔl wʊmən huz hɛɹ wɑz biɪŋ stʃɹoʊk baɪ ə dɑɹk, skwɛɹ-feɪst sʌldəm. ə deɪmeɪnz feɪs wɑz ɔlweɪz dɪsɛptɪv  -  ðeɪ eɪdʒ sloʊli ən lɪvd ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm  -  bʌt ðɪs wʌn hæɾ ə dɪfɝəns i hæd lɝn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əz bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə ðoʊz u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ɛɛs sədaɪ. "wʌɾ ɪkskjus dɪd jə jus tə ɡɛɾ ɔl ə ðɛm aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ət wʌns?" hi æskt.

Musenge and Hartha touched fists to heart, and Karede returned their salute, but his eyes went to the damane. To one in particular, a small woman whose hair was being stroked by a dark, square-faced sul'dam. A damane's face was always deceptive  -  they aged slowly and lived a very long time  -  but this one had a difference he had learned to recognize as belonging to those who called themselves Aes Sedai. "What excuse did you use to get all of them out of the city at once?" he asked.

"ɛksɝsaɪz, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl," mɛlɪtin ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə ɹaɪ smaɪl. "ɛvɹiwʌn ɔlweɪz bɪlivz ɛksɝsaɪz." ɪt wɑz sɛd ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn ɪn tʃɹuθ niɾəd noʊ dɝsʌldəm tə tʃɹeɪn əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi əɹ əɹ sʌldəm, bʌt mɛlɪtin, wɪð lɛs blæk ðən ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ, wɑz ɪkspɪɹiənst ɪn mɔɹ ðən əɹ kɹæft, ən ʃi nu wʌɾ i wɑz ɹɪli æskɪŋ. hi hæd ɹɪkwɛstɪd ðət mjuzənʒ bɹɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə deɪmeɪn, ɪf i kʊd. "nʌn ʌv əs wəd bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd, bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl. nɛvɝ fəɹ ðɪs. əz fəɹ maɪələn. . . . " ðət mʌs bi ðə fɔɹmɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "æftɝ wi lɛf ðə sɪɾi, wi toʊl ðə deɪmeɪn waɪ wi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ. ɪts ɔlweɪz bɛst ɪf ðeɪ noʊ wʌts ɪkspɛktəd. wiv bɪn kɑmɪŋ maɪələn ɛvɝ sɪns. ʃi lʌvz ðə haɪ leɪɾi.

"Exercise, Banner-General," Melitene replied with a wry smile. "Everyone always believes exercise." It was said the High Lady Tuon in truth needed no der'sul'dam to train her property or her sul'dam, but Melitene, with less black than gray in her long hair, was experienced in more than her craft, and she knew what he was really asking. He had requested that Musenge bring a pair of damane, if he could. "None of us would be left behind, Banner-General. Never for this. As for Mylen. . . . " That must be the former Aes Sedai. "After we left the city, we told the damane why we were going. It's always best if they know what's expected. We've been calming Mylen ever since. She loves the High Lady.

ðeɪ ɔl du, bʌt maɪələn wɝʃəps əɹ əz ðoʊ ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi sæɾ ɑn ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn. ɪf maɪələn ɡɛts əɹ hænz ɑn wʌn ə ðiz 'ɛɛs sədaɪ,'" ʃi tʃʌkəld, "wil əv tə bi kwɪk tə kip ðə wʊmən fɹəm biɪŋ tu bæɾɝd tə bi wɝθ liʃɪŋ."

They all do, but Mylen worships her as though she already sat on the Crystal Throne. If Mylen gets her hands on one of these 'Aes Sedai,'" she chuckled, "we'll have to be quick to keep the woman from being too battered to be worth leashing."

"aɪ si noʊ kɑz fəɹ læftɝ," hɑɹɾə ɹʌmbəld. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz ivən mɔɹ wɛðɝɾ ən ɡɹɪzəl ðən mjuzənʒ, wɪð lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ mʌstæʃɪz ən aɪz laɪk blæk stoʊnz stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛlmət. hi hæd bɪn ə ɡɑɹɾənɝ sɪns bɪfɔɹ kɛɹidz fɑðɝ wɑz bɔɹn, meɪbi bɪfɔɹ ɪz ɡɹændfɑðɝ. "wi hæv noʊ tɑɹɡət. wəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ðə wɪn ɪn ə nɛt." mɛlɪtin soʊbɝd kwɪkli, ən mjuzənʒ bɪɡæn tə lʊk ɡɹɪmɝ ðən hɑɹɾə, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. ɪn tɛn deɪz, ðə pipəl ðeɪ sɔt wʊɾə pʊt mɛni maɪlz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə bɛs ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəd sɛnd wəd nɑt bi soʊ bleɪɾənt əz tə hɛd du ist æftɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ ðə ɹuz ə dʒəhænə, nɔɹ soʊ stupəd tə əz tə hɛd tu kloʊs tə nɔɹθ, jɛt ðət lɛft ə væst ən ɛvɝ ɪkspændɪŋ ɛɹiə tə bi sɝtʃt. "ðɛn wi mʌs bɪɡɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ nɛts wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ," kɛɹid sɛd, "æn spɹɛɾ əm faɪnli." mjuzənʒ ən hɑɹɾə nɑɾəd. fəɹ ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd, wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, wəd bi dʌn. ivən tə kætʃɪŋ ðə wɪnd.

"I see no cause for laughter," Hartha rumbled. The Ogier was even more weathered and grizzled than Musenge, with long gray mustaches and eyes like black stones staring out of his helmet. He had been a Gardener since before Karede's father was born, maybe before his grandfather. "We have no target. We are trying to catch the wind in a net." Melitene sobered quickly, and Musenge began to look grimmer than Hartha, if that was possible. In ten days, the people they sought would have put many miles behind them. The best the White Tower could send would not be so blatant as to head due east after trying the ruse of Jehannah, nor so stupid to as to head too close to north, yet that left a vast and ever expanding area to be searched. "Then we must begin spreading our nets without delay," Karede said, "and spread them finely." Musenge and Hartha nodded. For the Deathwatch Guard, what must be done, would be done. Even to catching the wind.

tʃæptɝ faɪv

CHAPTER 5

ðə fɔɹdʒɪŋ ʌv ə hæmɝ i ɹæn izəli θɹu ðə naɪɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə snoʊ ðət kʌvɝd ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə ʃædoʊz, slɪpɪŋ θɹu ðə fɔɹəst, ðə munlaɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz klɪɹ tə hɪz aɪz əz ðə laɪɾ ə ðə sʌn. ə koʊld wɪn ɹʌfəld ɪz θɪk fɝ, ən sʌɾənli bɹɔɾ ə sɛn ðət meɪɾ ɪz hækəlz stæn ən ɪz hɑɹt ɹeɪs wɪð ə heɪtʃɹəd ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðət fəɹ ðə nɛvɝbɹn. heɪtʃɹəd, ən ə ʃʊɹ nɑlədʒ ə dɛθ kʌmɪŋ.

The Forging of a Hammer He ran easily through the night in spite of the snow that covered the ground. He was one with the shadows, slipping through the forest, the moonlight almost as clear to his eyes as the light of the sun. A cold wind ruffled his thick fur, and suddenly brought a scent that made his hackles stand and his heart race with a hatred greater than that for the Neverborn. Hatred, and a sure knowledge of death coming.

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɔɪsəz tə bi meɪd, nɑt naʊ. hi ɹæn hɑɹɾɝ, təwɔɹd dɛθ.

There were no choices to be made, not now. He ran harder, toward death.

pɛɹɪn woʊk əbɹʌpli ɪn ðə dip dɑɹknəs bɪfɔɹ dɔn, bɪniθ wʌn ə ðə haɪ-wil səplaɪ kɑɹts. koʊl hæd sipt ɪndə hɪz boʊnz fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊn dɪspaɪɾ ɪz hɛvi fɝ-laɪn kloʊk ən tu blæŋkəts, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə fɪtfəl bɹiz, nɑt stʃɹɔŋ əɹ stɛɾi ɪnʌf tə bi kɔld ə laɪt wɪnd, bʌɾ aɪsi.

Perrin woke abruptly in the deep darkness before dawn, beneath one of the high-wheeled supply carts. Cold had seeped into his bones from the ground despite his heavy fur-lined cloak and two blankets, and there was a fitful breeze, not strong or steady enough to be called a light wind, but icy.

wən i skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz feɪs wɪð ɡɔntələɾəd hænz, fɹɔs kɹækəld ɪn ɪz ʃɔɹt bɪɹd. ət list ɪt sim nɑt tə hæv snoʊɾ ɛni mɔɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt. tu ɔfən i hæɾ əweɪkən kʌvɝd wɪð ə dʌstɪŋ dɪspaɪt ðə ʃɛltɝ ʌv ə kɑɹt, ən snoʊfɔl meɪd θɪŋz dɪfəkəl fəɹ ðə skaʊts. hi wɪʃt i kəd spik wɪð ɛlaɪəs ðə seɪm weɪ hi tɔkt wɪð wʊlvz. ðən i wəd nɑɾ əv tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ðɪs ɛnləs weɪɾɪŋ.

When he scrubbed at his face with gauntleted hands, frost crackled in his short beard. At least it seemed not to have snowed any more during the night. Too often he had awakened covered with a dusting despite the shelter of a cart, and snowfall made things difficult for the scouts. He wished he could speak with Elyas the same way he talked with wolves. Then he would not have to endure this endless waiting.

wɪɹinəs klʌŋ tə hɪm laɪk ə sɛkən skɪn; hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl wən i hæd læs hæɾ ə saʊnd naɪts slip. slip, əɹ ðə læk ʌv ɪt, simd ənɪmpɔɹɾənt ɛniweɪ. ðiz deɪz, oʊnli ðə hiɾ ʌv æŋɡɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə kip muvɪŋ.

Weariness clung to him like a second skin; he could not recall when he had last had a sound night's sleep. Sleep, or the lack of it, seemed unimportant anyway. These days, only the heat of anger gave him the strength to keep moving.

hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ðə dʒɹim ðət hæd wækən hɪm. ɛvɹi naɪɾ i leɪ daʊn ɪkspɛktɪŋ naɪtmɛɹz, ən ɛvɹi naɪt ðeɪ keɪm. ɪn ðə wɝst, hi faʊn feɪl dɛd, əɹ nɛvɝ faʊn hɝ. ðoʊz woʊk ɪm ʌp ɪn ʃɪvɝɪŋ swɛts. ɛniθɪŋ lɛs hɔɹəbəl, hi slɛp θɹu, əɹ oʊnli hæf-woʊk wɪð tʃɹɑləks kʌɾɪŋ ɪm ʌp əlaɪv fəɹ ðə kʊkpɑɾ əɹ ə dʒɹæɡkɝ iɾɪŋ ɪz soʊl. ðɪs dʒɹim wɑz feɪɾɪŋ kwɪkli, ɪn ðə mænɝ ə dʒɹimz, jɛɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd biɪŋ ə wʊlf ən smɛlɪŋ. . . . wʌt? sʌmθɪŋ wʊlvz heɪɾəd mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ dɪd mɹdʒɹɑl. sʌmθɪŋ ə wʊlf nu wəd kɪl hɪm. ðə nɑlədʒ i hæd hæɾ ɪn ðə dʒɹim wɑz ɡɔn; oʊnli veɪɡ ɪmpɹɛʃənz ɹɪmeɪnd. hi hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, ðət ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðɪs wɝld wɛɹ dɛd wʊlvz lɪvd ɑn ən ðə lɪvɪŋ kəd ɡoʊ tə kənsʌl ðɛm. ðə wʊlf dʒɹim ɔlweɪz ɹɪmeɪn klɪɹ ɪn ɪz hɛɾ æftɝ i lɛft, wɛðɝ i hæd ɡɔn ðəɹ kɑnʃəsli əɹ nɑt. jɛt ðɪs dʒɹim stɪl simd ɹil, ən sʌmhaʊ ɝdʒənt. laɪɪŋ moʊʃənləs ɑn ɪz bæk, hi sɛn ɪz maɪn kwɛstɪŋ, filɪŋ fəɹ wʊlvz. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd juzɪŋ wʊlvz tə hɛlp ɪz hʌnt, tə noʊ əveɪl. kənvɪnsɪŋ əm tə teɪk ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðə duɪŋz ə toʊlɛɡz wɑz dɪfəkəlt, tə seɪ ðə list. ðeɪ əvɔɪɾəd lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾiz ə mɛn, ən fəɹ ðɛm, hæf ə dʌzən wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə steɪ klɪɹ ʌv. mɛn tʃeɪst əweɪ ɡeɪm, ən moʊs mɛn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ə wʊlf ɑn saɪt. hɪz θɔts faʊnd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, æftɝ ə taɪm, hi tʌtʃt wʊlvz, əɾ ə dɪstəns. haʊ fɑɹ, hi kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk kætʃɪŋ ə wɪspɝ ɔlmoʊst ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪɹɪŋ. ə lɔŋ weɪ. ðət wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ. dɪspaɪt skæɾɝd vɪlədʒəz ən mænɝz ən ivən ði əkeɪʒənəl taʊn, ðɪs wɑz pɹaɪm kʌntʃɹi fəɹ wʊlvz, əntʌtʃt fɔɹəs fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, wɪð plɛnti ʌv dɪɹ ən smɔlɝ ɡeɪm. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə fɔɹmæləɾi tə spikɪŋ wɪð ə pæk jə wɝ nɑt pɑɹɾ ʌv.

He did not think it was the dream that had wakened him. Every night he lay down expecting nightmares, and every night they came. In the worst, he found Faile dead, or never found her. Those woke him up in shivering sweats. Anything less horrible, he slept through, or only half-woke with Trollocs cutting him up alive for the cookpot or a Draghkar eating his soul. This dream was fading quickly, in the manner of dreams, yet he remembered being a wolf and smelling. . . . What? Something wolves hated more than they did Myrddraal. Something a wolf knew would kill him. The knowledge he had had in the dream was gone; only vague impressions remained. He had not been in the wolf dream, that reflection of this world where dead wolves lived on and the living could go to consult them. The wolf dream always remained clear in his head after he left, whether he had gone there consciously or not. Yet this dream still seemed real, and somehow urgent. Lying motionless on his back, he sent his mind questing, feeling for wolves. He had tried using wolves to help his hunt, to no avail. Convincing them to take an interest in the doings of twolegs was difficult, to say the least. They avoided large parties of men, and for them, half a dozen was large enough to stay clear of. Men chased away game, and most men tried to kill a wolf on sight. His thoughts found nothing, but then, after a time, he touched wolves, at a distance. How far, he could not be sure, but it was like catching a whisper almost on the edge of hearing. A long way. That was strange. Despite scattered villages and manors and even the occasional town, this was prime country for wolves, untouched forest for the most part, with plenty of deer and smaller game. There was always a formality to speaking with a pack you were not part of.

pəlaɪtli, hi sɛn ɪz neɪm əmʌŋ wʊlvz, jʌŋ bʊl, ʃɛɹɾ ɪz sɛnt, ən ɹəsiv ðɛɹz ɪn ɹɪplaɪ, lifhʌntɝ ən tɔl bɛɹ, waɪt teɪl ən fɛðɝ ən θʌndɝ mɪst, ə kæskeɪɾ ʌv ʌðɝz.

Politely, he sent his name among wolves, Young Bull, shared his scent, and received theirs in reply, Leafhunter and Tall Bear, White Tail and Feather and Thunder Mist, a cascade of others.

ɪt wɑz ə saɪzəbəl pæk, ən lifhʌntɝ, ə fimeɪl wɪð ə fil ə kwaɪət sɝɾənti, wɑz ðɛɹ liɾɝ.

It was a sizable pack, and Leafhunter, a female with a feel of quiet certainty, was their leader.

fɛðɝ, klɛvɝ ən ɪn ɪz pɹaɪm, wɑz əɹ meɪt. ðeɪ hæd hɝɾ ə jʌŋ bʊl, wɝ iɡɝ tə spik wɪð ðə fɹɛn ə ðə feɪbəld lɔŋ tuθ, ðə fɝs tu-lɛɡz u hæd lɝn tə spik wɪð wʊlvz æftɝ ə ɡæp ə taɪm ðət kæɹid ðə fil ʌv eɪdʒəz vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə mɪsts ə ðə pæst. ɪt wɑz ɔl ə tɔɹən ʌv ɪmədʒəz ən mɛmɹiz ə sɛns ðəɾ ɪz maɪn tɝn ɪndə wɝdz, əz ðə wɝdz i θɔt sʌmhaʊ bɪkeɪm ɪmədʒəz ən sɛns ðeɪ kəɾ ʌndɝstænd.

Feather, clever and in his prime, was her mate. They had heard of Young Bull, were eager to speak with the friend of the fabled Long Tooth, the first two-legs who had learned to speak with wolves after a gap of time that carried the feel of Ages vanished into the mists of the past. It was all a torrent of images and memories of scents that his mind turned into words, as the words he thought somehow became images and scents they could understand.

ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ wɑnə lɝn, hi θɔt, wʌns ðə ɡɹiɾɪŋz wɝ dʌn. wʌt wəɾ ə wʊlf heɪt mɔɹ ðən ðə nɛvɝbɹn? hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹikɔl ðə sɛn fɹəm ðə dʒɹim, tə æd ðæt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm ɪz mɛmɹi. sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ə wʊlf noʊz minz dɛθ.

There is something I want to learn, he thought, once the greetings were done. What would a wolf hate more than the Neverborn? He tried to recall the scent from the dream, to add that, but it was gone from his memory. Something that a wolf knows means death.

saɪləns ænsɝd hɪm, ən ə θɹɛɾ ə fɪɹ blɛndəd wɪð heɪtʃɹəɾ ən dɪtɝməneɪʃən ən ɹɪlʌktəns. hi hæd fɛl fɪɹ fɹəm wʊlvz bɪfɔɹ - əbʌv ɔl θɪŋz ðeɪ fɪɹd ðə waɪldfaɪɝ ðət ɹeɪs θɹu ə fɔɹəst, əɹ soʊ hi wʊɾə sɛd - bʌt ðɪs wɑz ðə pɹɪklɪŋ sɔɹɾ ə fɪɹ ðət meɪɾ ə mænz skɪn kɹɔl, meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ ən dʒʌmp ət θɪŋz ənsin. leɪst wɪð ðə ɹɛzəluʃən tə ɡoʊ ɑn noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt, ɪt fɛl kloʊs tə tɛɹɝ. wʊlvz nɛvɝ ɪkspɪɹiəns ðət kaɪndə dʒɹɛd. ɪksɛp ðət ðiz dɪd.

Silence answered him, and a thread of fear blended with hatred and determination and reluctance. He had felt fear from wolves before - above all things they feared the wildfire that raced through a forest, or so he would have said - but this was the prickling sort of fear that made a man's skin crawl, made him shiver and jump at things unseen. Laced with the resolution to go on no matter what, it felt close to terror. Wolves never experienced that kind of dread. Except that these did.

wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz kɑnʃəsnəs, ə dɪlɪbɝɪɾ ækt ə ʃʌɾɪŋ ɪm aʊt, əntɪl oʊnli lifhʌntɝ ɹɪmeɪnd. ðə læs hʌn ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, ən ðən ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɑz ɡɔn. dɪɾ aɪ əfɛnd? hi sɛnt. aɪaɪaɪ dɪd, ɪt wɑz ɪn ɪɡnɝəns. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹɪplaɪ. ðiz wʊlvz, ət list, wəd nɑt spik wɪð ɪm əɡɛn, nɑɾ ɛni taɪm sun.

One by one they faded from his consciousness, a deliberate act of shutting him out, until only Leafhunter remained. The Last Hunt is coming, she said at last, and then she also was gone. Did I offend? he sent. III did, it was in ignorance. But there was no reply. These wolves, at least, would not speak with him again, not any time soon.

ðə læs hʌn ɪz kʌmɪŋ. ðət wɑz wʌt wʊlvz kɔl ðə læs bæɾəl, tɑɹmən ɡdən. ðeɪ nu ðeɪ wəd bi ðɛɹ, ət ðə faɪnəl kɑnfɹənteɪʃən bɪtwin ðə laɪɾ ən ðə ʃædoʊ, ðoʊ waɪ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn. səm θɪŋz wɝ feɪɾɪd, əz ʃʊɹ əz ðə ɹaɪz ən fɔl ə ðə sʌn ən ðə mun, ən ɪt wɑz feɪɾɪd ðət mɛni wʊlvz wəd daɪ ɪn ðə læs hʌnt. wʌt ðeɪ fɪɹd wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ sɛns ðəɾ i ɔlsoʊ hæd tə bi ðɛɹ, wɑz mɛn tə bi ət list, bʌɾ ɪf ðə læs bæɾəl keɪm sun, hi wəd nɑt bi. hi hæɾ ə dʒɑb ʌv wɝk ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ðəɾ i kəd nɑt ʃɝk - wəd nɑt! -  ivən fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən.

The Last Hunt is coming. That was what wolves called the Last Battle, Tarmon Gai'don. They knew they would be there, at the final confrontation between the Light and the Shadow, though why was something they could not explain. Some things were fated, as sure as the rise and fall of the sun and the moon, and it was fated that many wolves would die in the Last Hunt. What they feared was something else. Perrin had a strong sense that he also had to be there, was meant to be at least, but if the Last Battle came soon, he would not be. He had a job of work in front of him that he could not shirk - would not! -  even for Tarmon Gai'don.

pʊɾɪŋ neɪmləs fɪɹz ən ðə læs bæɾəl əlaɪk aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd, hi fʌmbəld ɪz ɡɔnləts ɔf ən fɛlt ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkət fəɹ ðə lɛŋθ ə ɹɔhaɪd kɔɹɾ i kɛp ðɛɹ. ɪn ə mɔɹnɪŋ ɹɪtʃuəl, hɪz fɪŋɡɝz meɪɾ ənʌðɝ nɑt məkænɪkli, ðən slɪd daʊn ðə kɔɹd, kaʊntɪŋ. twɛnti-tu nɑts. twɛnti-tu mɔɹnɪŋz sɪns feɪl wɑz kɪdnæpt.

Putting nameless fears and the Last Battle alike out of his mind, he fumbled his gauntlets off and felt in his coat pocket for the length of rawhide cord he kept there. In a morning ritual, his fingers made another knot mechanically, then slid down the cord, counting. Twenty-two knots. Twenty-two mornings since Faile was kidnapped.

ət ðə stɑɹt, hi hæd nɑt θɔt ðəɹ wɑz nid tə kip kaʊnt. ðət fɝs deɪ, hi hæd bɪlivd i wɑz koʊld ən nʌm bʌt foʊkəst, jɛt lʊkɪŋ bæk i kəd si hi hæd bɪn oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ ənbaʊn ɹeɪdʒ ən ə kənsumɪŋ nid tə faɪn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ əz fæst əz pɑsəbəl. mɛn fɹəm ʌðɝ klænz hæd bɪn əmʌŋ ði il u hæd stoʊlən feɪl, jɛɾ ɑn ði ɛvəɾəns, moʊst wɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən ðət wɑz haʊ hi θɔɾ ə ðɛm. ðə nid tə ɹɪp feɪl əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm, bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bi hɝt, hæd ɡɹɪpt ɪm baɪ ðə θɹoʊt tɪl i ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt. hi wəd ɹɛskju ði ʌðɝ wɪmən kæptʃɝd wɪð hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt səmtaɪmz i hæd tə lɪs ðɛɹ neɪmz ɪn ɪz hɛd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i dɪd nɑt fɝɡɛɾ əm ɪntaɪɝli. æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən, ən ɪz lidʒ wʊmən. ɪt stɪl simd ɔf-kɪltɝ tə hæv ɛniwʌn oʊθswɔɹn tə hɪm, ɪspɛʃli ə kwin - hi wɑz ə blæksmɪθ! hi hæd bɪn ə blæksmɪθ, wʌns - bʌɾ i hæd ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz təwɔɹɾ æliændɝ, ən ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əv bɪn ɪn deɪnʒɝ ɪksɛp fəɹ hɪm. beɪn ə ðə blæk ɹɑk ʃɝəɾ ən kiæɾ ə ðə stoʊnz ɹɪvɝ ɡoʊʃin, il meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ u hæd fɑloʊd feɪl tə ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə. ðeɪ hæd feɪs tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, əz wɛl, wən pɛɹɪn niɾəd ɛvɹi hæn ðət kəd ɹeɪz ə wɛpən, ən ðəɾ ɝn əm ðə ɹaɪt tə kɔl ɑn hɪm. ɹɛlə ʃiɡoʊ ən lətʃəl ɑldɔɹwɪn, tu fulɪʃ jʌŋ wɪmən u θɔt ðeɪ kəd lɝn tə bi il, əɹ səm stʃɹeɪnʒ vɝʒən ʌv il. ðeɪ wɝ oʊθswɔɹn tə feɪl, ən soʊ wɑz meɪaɪɡdɪn dɔɹleɪn, ə pɛniləs ɹɛfjʊdʒi feɪl hæd teɪkən ʌndɝ əɹ wɪŋ əz wʌn ə hɝ meɪdz. hi kəd nɑɾ əbændən feɪlz pipəl. feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. ðə lɪɾəni keɪm bæk tə hɝ, hɪz waɪf, ðə bɹɛθ ə hɪz laɪf. wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, hi klʌtʃt ðə kɔɹd soʊ taɪtli ðət ðə nɑts ɪmpɹɛs ðɛmsɛlvz peɪnfəli ɑn ə hæn hɑɹɾənd baɪ lɔŋ deɪz swɪŋɪŋ ðə hæmɝ əɾ ə fɔɹdʒ. laɪt, twɛnti-tu deɪz!

At the start, he had not thought there was need to keep count. That first day, he had believed he was cold and numb but focused, yet looking back he could see he had been overwhelmed by unbound rage and a consuming need to find the Shaido as fast as possible. Men from other clans had been among the Aiel who had stolen Faile, yet on the evidence, most were Shaido, and that was how he thought of them. The need to rip Faile away from them, before she could be hurt, had gripped him by the throat till he almost choked. He would rescue the other women captured with her, of course, but sometimes he had to list their names in his head to make sure he did not forget them entirely. Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan, and his liege woman. It still seemed off-kilter to have anyone oathsworn to him, especially a queen - he was a blacksmith! He had been a blacksmith, once - but he had responsibilities toward Alliandre, and she would never have been in danger except for him. Bain of the Black Rock Shaarad and Chiad of the Stones River Goshien, Aiel Maidens of the Spear who had followed Faile to Ghealdan and Amadicia. They had faced Trollocs in the Two Rivers, as well, when Perrin needed every hand that could raise a weapon, and that earned them the right to call on him. Arrela Shiego and Lacile Aldorwin, two foolish young women who thought they could learn to be Aiel, or some strange version of Aiel. They were oathsworn to Faile, and so was Maighdin Dorlain, a penniless refugee Faile had taken under her wing as one of her maids. He could not abandon Faile's people. Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara. The litany came back to her, his wife, the breath of his life. With a groan, he clutched the cord so tightly that the knots impressed themselves painfully on a hand hardened by long days swinging the hammer at a forge. Light, twenty-two days!

wɝkɪŋ aɪɝn hæd tɔɾ ɪm ðət heɪst ɹuən mɛɾəl, bʌɾ ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, hi hæd bɪn heɪsti, tʃɹævlɪŋ saʊθwɝd θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz kɹieɪɾəd baɪ ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild, ðə tu æʃəmən, tə wɛɹ ðə fɑɹðəs tʃɹeɪsəz ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd bɪn faʊnd, ðən lipɪŋ saʊθ əɡɛn, ðə dɝɛkʃən ðɛɹ tʃɹæks wɛnt, əz sun əz ði æʃəmən kəd meɪk mɔɹ ɡeɪtweɪz. fɹɛɾɪŋ ɛvɹi aʊɝ ɪt tʊk əm tə ɹɛs fɹəm meɪkɪŋ ðə fɝst ən hoʊldɪŋ əm oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə pæs θɹu, hɪz maɪnd wɑz iɾən ʌp wɪð fɹiɪŋ feɪl əɾ ɛni kɑst. wʌɾ i faʊnd wɝ deɪz ʌv ɪnkɹisɪŋ peɪn əz ðə skaʊts spɹɛd fɑɹðɝ ən fɑɹðɝ θɹu ʌnɪnhæbəɾɪd wɪldɝnəs wɪθaʊt loʊkeɪɾɪŋ ðə slaɪɾəst saɪn ðəɾ ɛniwʌn hæd bɪn ðət weɪ bɪfɔɹ, əntɪl i nu hi hæd tə ɹitʃɹeɪs ɪz pæθ, fɹɪɾɝɪŋ əweɪ mɔɹ deɪz tə kʌvɝ ɡɹaʊn ði æʃəmən hæd teɪkən ɪm əkɹɔs ɪn ə stɛp, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɛni ɪndəkeɪʃən ʌv wɛɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd tɝn əsaɪd.

Working iron had taught him that haste ruined metal, but in the beginning, he had been hasty, Traveling southward through gateways created by Grady and Neald, the two Asha'man, to where the farthest traces of the Shaido had been found, then leaping south again, the direction their tracks went, as soon as the Asha'man could make more gateways. Fretting every hour it took them to rest from making the first and holding them open long enough for everyone to pass through, his mind was eaten up with freeing Faile at any cost. What he found were days of increasing pain as the scouts spread farther and farther through uninhabited wilderness without locating the slightest sign that anyone had been that way before, until he knew he had to retrace his path, frittering away more days to cover ground the Asha'man had taken him across in a step, searching for any indication of where the Shaido had turned aside.

hi ʃʊɾə noʊn ðeɪ wəd tɝn. saʊθ tʊk əm təwɔɹd wɔɹmɝ lænz, wɪθaʊt ðə snoʊ ðət sim soʊ stʃɹeɪnʒ tə il, jɛɾ ɪt tʊk əm kloʊsɝ tə ðə sintʃæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, əz wɛl. hi nu əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn, ən i ʃʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə lɝn! ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ pɪlɪdʒ, nɑɾ ə faɪt wɪð sintʃæn ən deɪmeɪn. deɪz ə sloʊ mɑɹtʃɪŋ wɪð ðə skaʊts fænɪŋ aʊɾ əhɛd, deɪz wən fɔlɪŋ snoʊ blaɪndɪɾ ivən ði il ən fɔɹst əm ɔl tə ə tʃeɪfɪŋ hɔlt, əntɪl faɪnəli dʒɑndɪn bæɹən faʊn ə tʃɹi skɹeɪp baɪ ə wæɡən ən ɛlaɪəs dʌɡ ə bɹoʊkən il spɪɹ ʃæft fɹəm bɪniθ ðə snoʊ. ən pɛɹɪn ət læs tɝn ist, ət moʊs tu deɪz saʊθ ʌv wɛɹ i hæd tʃɹævəl tə ðə fɝs taɪm. hi hæd wɑntəd tə haʊl wən i ɹilaɪz ðæt, jɛɾ i kɛpt ə taɪt hoʊld ɑn hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd nɑt ɡɪv weɪ, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ən ɪntʃ, nɑt wən feɪl wɑz dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn hɪm. ðət wɑz wən i bɪɡæn tə hʌzbən ɪz æŋɡɝ, bɪɡæn tə fɔɹdʒ ɪt.

He should have known they would turn. South took them toward warmer lands, without the snow that seemed so strange to Aiel, yet it took them closer to the Seanchan in Ebou Dar, as well. He knew about the Seanchan, and he should have expected the Shaido to learn! They were after pillage, not a fight with Seanchan and damane. Days of slow marching with the scouts fanning out ahead, days when falling snow blinded even the Aiel and forced them all to a chafing halt, until finally Jondyn Barran found a tree scraped by a wagon and Elyas dug a broken Aiel spear shaft from beneath the snow. And Perrin at last turned east, at most two days south of where he had Traveled to the first time. He had wanted to howl when he realized that, yet he kept a tight hold on himself. He could not give way, not so much as an inch, not when Faile was depending on him. That was when he began to husband his anger, began to forge it.

hɝ kɪdnæpɝz hæd ɡeɪn ə lɔŋ lɛd kəz i wɑz heɪsti, bʌt sɪns ðɛn, hi hæd bɪn əz kɛɹfəl əz i hæd bɪn ɪn ə smɪθi. hɪz æŋɡɝ wɑz hɑɹɾənd ən ʃeɪp tə ə pɝpəs. sɪns faɪndɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz tʃɹeɪl əɡɛn, hi hæd tʃɹævəl noʊ fɑɹðɝ ɪn wʌn dʒʌmp ðən ðə skaʊts kəd ɡoʊ ən kʌm bɪtwin sʌnɹaɪz ən sʌnsɛt, ən ɪt wɑz wɛl ðəɾ i hæd bɪn kɔʃəs, kəz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʃeɪnʒd dɝɛkʃənz sʌɾənli sɛvɹəl taɪmz, zɪɡzæɡɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd nɑt dɪsaɪɾ ɑn ə dɛstəneɪʃən. əɹ meɪbi ðeɪ hæd tɝn tə dʒɔɪn ʌðɝz ə ðɛɹ kaɪnd. ɔl i hæd tə ɡoʊ baɪ wɝ oʊl tʃɹeɪsəz, oʊl kæmps bɛɹid baɪ snoʊ, jɛɾ ɔl ə ðə skaʊts əɡɹid ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz nʌmbɝz hæd swoʊlən. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ət lis tu əɹ θɹi sɛps təɡɛðɝ, meɪbi mɔɹ, ə fɔɹməɾəbəl kwɔɹi tə hʌnt. sloʊli bʌt ʃʊɹli, ðoʊ, hi hæd bɪɡʌn oʊvɝteɪkɪŋ ðɛm. ðət wɑz wʌt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Her kidnappers had gained a long lead because he was hasty, but since then, he had been as careful as he had been in a smithy. His anger was hardened and shaped to a purpose. Since finding the Shaido's trail again, he had Traveled no farther in one jump than the scouts could go and come between sunrise and sunset, and it was well that he had been cautious, because the Shaido changed directions suddenly several times, zigzagging almost as though they could not decide on a destination. Or maybe they had turned to joined others of their kind. All he had to go by were old traces, old camps buried by snow, yet all of the scouts agreed the Shaido's numbers had swollen. There had to be at least two or three septs together, maybe more, a formidable quarry to hunt. Slowly but surely, though, he had begun overtaking them. That was what was important.

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kʌvɝd mɔɹ ɡɹaʊn ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ ðən i wʊɾə θɔt pɑsəbəl, ɡɪvən ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz ən ðə snoʊ, jɛt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn wɑz tʃɹækɪŋ ðɛm. pɝhæps ðeɪ bɪliv noʊ wʌn dɛɹd. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ hæd kæmp sɛvɹəl deɪz ɪn wʌn spɑt. æŋɡɝ fɔɹdʒ tə ə pɝpəs.

The Shaido covered more ground on the march than he would have thought possible, given their numbers and the snow, yet they did not seem to care whether anyone was tracking them. Perhaps they believed no one dared. Sometimes they had camped several days in one spot. Anger forged to a purpose.

ɹuən vɪlədʒəz ən smɔl taʊnz ən ɪsteɪts lɪɾɝd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz pæθ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hjumən loʊkəsts, stɔɹhaʊzəz ən væljəbəlz luɾəd, mɛn ən wɪmən kæɹiɾ ɔf əlɔŋ wɪð ðə laɪvstɑk. ɔfən noʊ wʌn ɹɪmeɪn baɪ ðə taɪm i ɝaɪvd, oʊnli ɛmpti haʊzɪz, ðə pipəl sikɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ fəɹ fud tə sɝvaɪv əntɪl spɹɪŋ. hi hæd kɹɔs ði ɪldɑɹ ɪndə ɔltɑɹə wɛɹ ə smɔl fɛɹi juz baɪ pɛdlɝz ən loʊkəl fɑɹmɝz, nɑt mɝtʃəns, wʌns ɹæn bɪtwin tu vɪlədʒəz ɑn ðə fɔɹəstəd ɹɪvɝbɑŋks. haʊ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd ɡɑɾən əkɹɔs, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ, bʌɾ i hæd ði æʃəmən meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz. ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə fɛɹi wɝ ðə ɹʌf stoʊn lændɪŋz ɑn iðɝ bæŋk, ən ðə fju ənbɝn stʃɹʌktʃɝz wɝ dɪzɝɾɪd ɪksɛp fəɹ θɹi slæt-ɹɪb fɛɹəl dɑɡz ðət slʌŋk əweɪ ət ðə saɪɾ ə hjumənz. æŋɡɝ hɑɹɾənd ən ʃeɪp fəɹ ə hæmɝ.

Ruined villages and small towns and estates littered the Shaido's path as if they were human locusts, storehouses and valuables looted, men and women carried off along with the livestock. Often no one remained by the time he arrived, only empty houses, the people seeking somewhere for food to survive until spring. He had crossed the Eldar into Altara where a small ferry used by peddlers and local farmers, not merchants, once ran between two villages on the forested riverbanks. How the Shaido had gotten across, he did not know, but he had the Asha'man make gateways. All that remained of the ferry were the rough stone landings on either bank, and the few unburned structures were deserted except for three slat-ribbed feral dogs that slunk away at the sight of humans. Anger hardened and shaped for a hammer.

jɛstɝdeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ, hi hæd kʌm tə ə taɪni vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ə dʌbəl hændfʊl ə stʌnd, dɝɾi-feɪst pipəl hæd stɛɹɾ ət ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə lænsɝz ən boʊmən ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst ət fɝs laɪt bɪhaɪn ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə meɪnɛðɝən ən ðə kɹɪmzən wʊlfzhɛd, ðə sɪlvɝ stɑɹz ʌv ɡildən ən ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ə min, fɑloʊd baɪ lɔŋ laɪnz ə haɪ-wil kɑɹts ən stʃɹɪŋz ə ɹimaʊns. ət fɝst saɪɾ ʌv ɡɔl ən ði ʌðɝ il, ðoʊz pipəl oʊvɝkeɪm ðɛɹ pɝæləsəs ən bɪɡæn ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ðə tʃɹiz ɪn pænɪk.

Yesterday morning, he had come to a tiny village where a double handful of stunned, dirty-faced people had stared at the hundreds of lancers and bowmen riding out of the forest at first light behind the Red Eagle of Manetheren and the crimson Wolfshead, the Silver Stars of Ghealdan and the Golden Hawk of Mayene, followed by long lines of high-wheeled carts and strings of remounts. At first sight of Gaul and the other Aiel, those people overcame their paralysis and began running for the trees in panic.

kætʃɪŋ ə fju tə ænsɝ kwɛstʃənz hæd bɪn dɪfəkəlt; ðeɪ wɝ ɹɛɾi tə ɹʌn ðɛmsɛlvz tə dɛθ ɹæðɝ ðən lɛɾ ən il nɪɹ. bɹaɪɾən hæd kənsɪstəɾ ʌv oʊnli ə dʌzən fæmliz, bʌt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd kæɹiɾ ɔf naɪn jʌŋ mɛn ən wɪmən fɹəm ðɛɹ, əlɔŋ wɪð ɔl ə ðɛɹ ænəməlz, oʊnli tu deɪz əɡoʊ. tu deɪz. ə hæmɝ wɑz ə tul wɪð ə pɝpəs, ən ə tɑɹɡət.

Catching a few to answer questions had been difficult; they were ready to run themselves to death rather than let an Aiel near. Brytan had consisted of only a dozen families, but the Shaido had carried off nine young men and women from there, along with all of their animals, only two days ago. Two days. A hammer was a tool with a purpose, and a target.

hi nu hi hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl, əɹ luz feɪl fɝɛvɝ, bʌt biɪŋ tu kɛɹfəl kəd luz hɝ, tu.

He knew he had to be careful, or lose Faile forever, but being too careful could lose her, too.

ɝli jɛstɝdeɪ hi hæd toʊl ðoʊz u wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əhɛd tə skaʊt ðət ðeɪ wɝ tə ɡoʊ fɑɹðɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ, pʊʃ ɑn hɑɹɾɝ, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ oʊnli wɪð ə fʊl tɝn ə ðə sʌn ənlɛs ðeɪ faʊn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sunɝ. ɪn ə lɪɾəl waɪl ðə sʌn wəd ɹaɪz, ən ət moʊst ə fju aʊɝz æftɝ ðæt, ɛlaɪəs ən ɡɔl ən ði ʌðɝz wəd ɹɪtɝn, ðə meɪɾənz ən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn i nu kəd tʃɹæk ə ʃædoʊ əkɹɔs wɔɾɝ. əz fæst əz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ muvd, ðə skaʊts kəd muv fæstɝ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɛnkʌmbɝd wɪð fæmliz ən wæɡənz ən kæptɪvz. ðɪs taɪm, ðeɪ wəd bi eɪbəl tə tɛl ɪm ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ. ðeɪ wʊd. hi nu ɪɾ ɪn ɪz boʊnz. ðə sɝɾənti floʊɾ ɪn ɪz veɪnz. hi wəd faɪn feɪl ən fɹi hɝ. ðət keɪm bɪfɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ, ivən lɪvɪŋ, soʊ lɔŋ əz i lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə əkɑmplɪʃ ɪt, jɛɾ i wɑz ə hæmɝ, naʊ, ən ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ tə əkɑmplɪʃ ɪt, ɛni weɪ əɾ ɔl, hi ɪntɛndəd tə hæmɝ ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪndə skɹæp.

Early yesterday he had told those who were going ahead to scout that they were to go farther than before, push on harder, returning only with a full turn of the sun unless they found the Shaido sooner. In a little while the sun would rise, and at most a few hours after that, Elyas and Gaul and the others would return, the Maidens and Two Rivers men he knew could track a shadow across water. As fast as the Shaido moved, the scouts could move faster. They were not encumbered with families and wagons and captives. This time, they would be able to tell him exactly where the Shaido were. They would. He knew it in his bones. The certainty flowed in his veins. He would find Faile and free her. That came before anything, even living, so long as he lived long enough to accomplish it, yet he was a hammer, now, and if there was any way to accomplish it, any way at all, he intended to hammer these Shaido into scrap.

tɔsɪŋ ðə blæŋkəts əsaɪd, pɛɹɪn tʌɡd ɪz ɡɔnləts bæk ɑn, ɡæðɝɾ ɪz æks fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt leɪ bɪsaɪd hɪm, ə hæf-mun bleɪd bæləns baɪ ə hɛvi spaɪk, ən ɹoʊld aʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpən, ɹaɪzɪŋ tə hɪz fiɾ ɑn tʃɹæmpəld, fɹoʊzən snoʊ. kɑɹts stʊɾ ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm ɪn ɹoʊz, ɪn wʌt hæd bɪn bɹaɪɾənz filz. ði ɝaɪvəl ə mɔɹ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, soʊ mɛni, ən ɑɹmd, wɪð ðɛɹ fɔɹən bænɝz, hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz ə ðə lɪɾəl vɪlədʒ kəɾ əbzɔɹb. əz sun əz pɛɹɪn wəd lɛt ðɛm, ðə pɪɾəfəl ɹɛmnən hæd flɛɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, kæɹiɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kəɾ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks ən ɑn dʒɹæɡslɛdz. ðeɪ hæd ɹʌn əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪf pɛɹɪn wɑz ənʌðɝ ʃeɪɾoʊ, nɑt lʊkɪŋ bæk fəɹ fɪɹ i wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm. əz i slɪp ði æks hæf θɹu ðə θɪk lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt, ə dipɝ ʃædoʊ bɪsaɪɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ kɑɹt ɡɹu tɔlɝ ən ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ə mæn swɑðd ɪn ə kloʊk ðət sim blæk ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd; ðə nɪɹbaɪ hɔɹslaɪnz θɪkən ði ɛɹ wɪð ðə smɛl ə sɛvɹəl θaʊzən ænəməlz, maʊns ən ɹimaʊns ən kɑɹt hɔɹsəz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə swit stɪŋk ə hɔɹs dʌŋ, bʌɾ i stɪl hæd kɑt ði ʌðɝz sɛn ɑn weɪkɪŋ.

Tossing the blankets aside, Perrin tugged his gauntlets back on, gathered his axe from where it lay beside him, a half-moon blade balanced by a heavy spike, and rolled out into the open, rising to his feet on trampled, frozen snow. Carts stood all around him in rows, in what had been Brytan's fields. The arrival of more strangers, so many, and armed, with their foreign banners, had been more than the survivors of the little village could absorb. As soon as Perrin would let them, the pitiful remnant had fled into the forest, carrying what they could on their backs and on dragsleds. They had run as hard as if Perrin was another Shaido, not looking back for fear he was following them. As he slipped the axe haft through the thick loop on his belt, a deeper shadow beside a nearby cart grew taller and resolved into a man swathed in a cloak that seemed black in the darkness. Perrin was not surprised; the nearby horselines thickened the air with the smell of several thousand animals, mounts and remounts and cart horses, not to mention the sweet stink of horse dung, but he still had caught the other's scent on waking.

mæn smɛl ɔlweɪz stʊɾ aʊt. bɪsaɪdz, ɛɹæm wɑz ɔlweɪz ðəɹ wən pɛɹɪn woʊk, weɪɾɪŋ. ə weɪnɪŋ sɪkəl mun loʊ ɪn ðə skaɪ stɪl ɡeɪv ɪnʌf laɪt fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊt ði ʌðɝ mænz feɪs, ɪf nɑt klɪɹli, ən ðə bɹæspəməl hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd slæntɪŋ ʌp pæst ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ɛɹæm hæd bɪn ə tɪŋkɝ wʌns, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəd bi əɡɛn, ivən ɪf i dɪd wɛɹ ə bɹaɪtli stʃɹaɪp tɪŋkɝ koʊt.

Man smell always stood out. Besides, Aram was always there when Perrin woke, waiting. A waning sickle moon low in the sky still gave enough light for him to make out the other man's face, if not clearly, and the brasspommeled hilt of his sword slanting up past his shoulder. Aram had been a Tinker once, but Perrin did not think he would be again, even if he did wear a brightly striped Tinker coat.

ðəɹ wɑz ə fɹaʊnɪŋ hɑɹdnəs əbaʊɾ ɛɹæm naʊ ðət mun ʃædoʊz kəd nɑt haɪd. hi stʊɾ əz ðoʊ ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɔ ðət sɔɹd, ən sɪns feɪl wɑz teɪkən, æŋɡɝ simd ə pɝmənən pɑɹɾ ə hɪz sɛnt. ə ɡɹeɪt dil hæd tʃeɪnʒd wən feɪl wɑz teɪkən. ɛniweɪ, pɛɹɪn ʌndɝstʊɾ æŋɡɝ. hi hæd nɑt, nɑt ɹɪli, bɪfɔɹ feɪl wɑz teɪkən.

There was a frowning hardness about Aram now that moon shadows could not hide. He stood as though ready to draw that sword, and since Faile was taken, anger seemed a permanent part of his scent. A great deal had changed when Faile was taken. Anyway, Perrin understood anger. He had not, not really, before Faile was taken.

"ðeɪ wɑnə si ju, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," ɛɹæm sɛd, dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd tu dɪm fɔɹmz fɑɹðɝ əweɪ bɪtwin ðə laɪnz ə kɑɹts. ðə wɝdz keɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə feɪn mɪst ɪn ðə koʊld ɛɹ. "aɪ toʊld əm tə lɛt jə slip." ɪt wɑz ə fɔlt ɛɹæm hæd, lʊkɪŋ æftɝ ɪm tu mʌtʃ, ʌnəskt.

"They want to see you, Lord Perrin," Aram said, jerking his head toward two dim forms farther away between the lines of carts. The words came out in a faint mist in the cold air. "I told them to let you sleep." It was a fault Aram had, looking after him too much, unasked.

tɛstɪŋ ði ɛɹ, pɛɹɪn sɛpɝeɪɾəd aʊt ðə sɛns ə ðoʊz tu ʃædoʊz fɹəm ðə mæskɪŋ smɛl ə ðə hɔɹsəz. "aɪl si ðɛm naʊ. hæv stɛpɝ ɹɛɾid fəɹ mi, ɛɹæm." hi tʃɹaɪd tə bi ɪn ðə sæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kæmp woʊk. pɑɹtli ðət wɑz kəz stændɪŋ stɪl fəɹ lɔŋ sim bɪɑn hɪm. stændɪŋ stɪl wɑz nɑt kætʃɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. pɑɹtli ɪt wɑz tə əvɔɪd hævɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ ɛniwʌnz kʌmpəni hi kəɾ əvɔɪd. hi wʊɾə ɡɔn aʊt wɪð ðə skaʊts hɪmsɛlf ɪf ðə mɛn ən wɪmən ɔlɹɛɾi duɪŋ ðət dʒɑb wɝ nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ əɾ ɪt ðən hi.

Testing the air, Perrin separated out the scents of those two shadows from the masking smell of the horses. "I'll see them now. Have Stepper readied for me, Aram." He tried to be in the saddle before the rest of the camp woke. Partly that was because standing still for long seemed beyond him. Standing still was not catching the Shaido. Partly it was to avoid having to share anyone's company he could avoid. He would have gone out with the scouts himself if the men and women already doing that job were not so much better at it than he.

"jɛs, maɪ lɔɹd." ə dʒæədnəs ɛntɝɾ ɛɹæmz sɛn əz i tʃɹʌdʒd əweɪ əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ, bʌt pɛɹɪn bɛɹli noʊɾəd ɪt. oʊnli sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt wəd meɪk sɛbæn beɪlwɝ ɹut hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə hɪz blæŋkəts ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən əz fəɹ sɛlən dɛɹənɡəl. . . . beɪlwɝ əpɪɹd skɪni ivən ɪn ə bʌlki kloʊk, hɪz pɪntʃt feɪs ɔl bʌt hɪɾən ɪn ðə dip hʊd. hæɾ i stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə hʌntʃɪŋ, hi stɪl wʊɾə bɪn ət moʊst ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən ðə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, hu wɑz nɑt tɔl. wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf, hi wɑz hɑpɪŋ fɹəm wʌn fʊt tə ði ʌðɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðə koʊl ðət mʌs bi soʊkɪŋ θɹu hɪz buts. sɛlənd, ɪn ə mænz dɑɹk koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz, meɪɾ ə ɡʊɾ ɛfɝɾ əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ dɪspaɪt ðə fɛðɝi waɪt ðət mɑɹkt ɛvɹi bɹɛθ. ʃi wɑz ʃɪvɝɪŋ, bʌt mænədʒ tə swæɡɝ stændɪŋ stɪl, wɪð wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk ən ə ɡlʌv hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɝ sɔɹd. ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk wɑz loʊɝd, tu, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ hɛɹ kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə teɪl ɪn ðə bæk ðət wɑz taɪɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk wɪð ə dɑɹk ɹɪbən. sɛlənd wɑz ðə liɾɝ ə ðoʊz fulz u wɑntəd tə bi ɪməteɪʃən il, il u kæɹid sɔɹdz. hɝ sɛnt wɑz sɑft ən θɪk, laɪk ə dʒɛli. ʃi wɑz wɝid. beɪlwɝ smɛld . . . ɪntɛnt . . . bʌt ðɛn, hi nɪɹli ɔlweɪz dɪd, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛni hit tə hɪz ɪntɛnsəɾi, oʊnli foʊkəs.

"Yes, my Lord." A jaggedness entered Aram's scent as he trudged away across the snow, but Perrin barely noted it. Only something important would make Sebban Balwer root himself out of his blankets in the dark, and as for Selande Darengil. . . . Balwer appeared skinny even in a bulky cloak, his pinched face all but hidden in the deep hood. Had he stood straight instead of hunching, he still would have been at most a hand taller than the Cairhienin woman, who was not tall. With his arms wrapped around himself, he was hopping from one foot to the other, trying to avoid the cold that must be soaking through his boots. Selande, in a man's dark coat and breeches, made a good effort at ignoring the temperature despite the feathery white that marked every breath. She was shivering, but managed to swagger standing still, with one side of her cloak thrown back and a gloved hand on the hilt of her sword. The hood of her cloak was lowered, too, exposing hair cut short except for the tail in the back that was tied at the nape of her neck with a dark ribbon. Selande was the leader of those fools who wanted to be imitation Aiel, Aiel who carried swords. Her scent was soft and thick, like a jelly. She was worried. Balwer smelled . . . intent . . . but then, he nearly always did, though there was never any heat to his intensity, only focus.

ðə skɪni lɪɾəl mæn stɑp hɑpɪŋ tə meɪk ə stɪf, hɝid baʊ. "ðə leɪɾi sɛlən əz nuz aɪ θɪŋk jə ʃəd hɪɹ fɹəm əɹ lɪps, maɪ lɔɹd." beɪlwɝz θɪn vɔɪs wɑz dʒɹaɪ ən pɹɪsaɪs, dʒʌs laɪk ɪts oʊnɝ. hi wəd saʊn ðə seɪm wɪð ɪz nɛk ɑn ə hɛdzmənz blɑk. "maɪ leɪɾi, ɪf jə wʊd?" hi wɑz oʊnli ə sɛkɹətɛɹi - feɪlz sɛkɹətɛɹi, ən pɛɹɪnz - ə fʌsi sɛlf-ɪfeɪsɪŋ fɛloʊ fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ən sɛlənd wɑz ə noʊbəlwʊmən, bʌt beɪlwɝ meɪd ðət mɔɹ ðən ə ɹɪkwɛst.

The skinny little man stopped hopping to make a stiff, hurried bow. "The Lady Selande has news I think you should hear from her lips, my Lord." Balwer's thin voice was dry and precise, just like its owner. He would sound the same with his neck on a headsman's block. "My Lady, if you would?" He was only a secretary - Faile's secretary, and Perrin's - a fussy self-effacing fellow for the most part, and Selande was a noblewoman, but Balwer made that more than a request.

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp saɪdweɪz ɡlæns, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ sɔɹd, ən pɛɹɪn tɛns tə ɡɹæb hɝ. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəɾ æktʃəli  dʒɹɔ ɑn ðə mæn, bʌt ðən əɡɛn, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf ə hɝ, əɹ ɛni ʌv əɹ ɹɪdɪkjələs fɹɛnz, tə pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən. beɪlwɝ mɪɹli wɑtʃt hɝ, hɪz hɛd tɪltəd tə wʌn saɪd, ən ɪz smɛl kæɹiɾ ɪmpeɪʃəns, nɑt kənsɝn.

She gave him a sharp sideways glance, shifting her sword, and Perrin tensed to grab her. He did not think she would actually draw on the man, but then again, he was not sure enough of her, or any of her ridiculous friends, to put it out of the question. Balwer merely watched her, his head tilted to one side, and his smell carried impatience, not concern.

wɪð ə tɔs ə hɝ hɛd, sɛlən tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə pɛɹɪn. "aɪ si ju, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz," ʃi bɪɡæn ɪn ðə kɹɪsp æksɛns ə kɛɹhin, bʌt, əwɛɹ ðəɾ i hæd lɪɾəl peɪʃəns fəɹ əɹ pɹitɛn il fɔɹmæləɾi, ʃi hɝiɾ ɑn. "aɪ hæv lɝn θɹi θɪŋz tənaɪt. fɝst, ðə list ɪmpɔɹɾənt, hɑviɑɹ ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət mæsimə sɛn ənʌðɝ ɹaɪɾɝ bæk təwɔɹɾ ɑmɑdɪʃiə jɛstɝdeɪ. nɛɹiən tʃɹaɪd tə fɑloʊ, bʌt lɔs hɪm."

With a toss of her head, Selande turned her attention to Perrin. "I see you, Lord Perrin Goldeneyes," she began in the crisp accents of Cairhien, but, aware that he had little patience for her pretend Aiel formality, she hurried on. "I have learned three things tonight. First, the least important, Haviar reported that Masema sent another rider back toward Amadicia yesterday. Nerion tried to follow, but lost him."

"tɛl nɛɹiən aɪ sɛɾ i ɪzən tə fɑloʊ ɛnibəɾi," pɛɹɪn toʊld əɹ ʃɑɹpli. "æn tɛl hɑviɑɹ ðə seɪm. ðeɪ ʃəd noʊ ðæt! ðeɪ ɑɹ tə wɑtʃ, lɪsən, ən ɹipɔɹt wʌt ðeɪ si ən hɪɹ, noʊ mɔɹ. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?" sɛlənd ɡeɪv ə kwɪk nɑd, ə θɔɹn ə fɪɹ ɛntɝɪŋ əɹ sɛn fəɹ ə moʊmənt. fɪɹ ə hɪm, pɛɹɪn səpoʊzd, fɪɹ ðəɾ i wɑz æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ. jɛloʊ aɪz ɑn ə mæn meɪd səm pipəl ənizi.

"Tell Nerion I said he isn't to follow anybody," Perrin told her sharply. "And tell Haviar the same. They should know that! They are to watch, listen, and report what they see and hear, no more. Do you understand me?" Selande gave a quick nod, a thorn of fear entering her scent for a moment. Fear of him, Perrin supposed, fear that he was angry with her. Yellow eyes on a man made some people uneasy.

hi tʊk ɪz hæn fɹəm ɪz æks ən klæsp boʊθ hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk.

He took his hand from his axe and clasped both hands behind his back.

hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən wɝ mɔɹ ə feɪlz tu dʌzən jʌŋ fulz, wʌn tɛɹən, ði ʌðɝ kɛɹhinɪn.

Haviar and Nerion were more of Faile's two dozen young fools, one Tairen, the other Cairhienin.

feɪl hæd juz ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm fəɹ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz, ə fæk ðət stɪl ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɪm fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðoʊ ʃi hæd toʊld ɪm tə hɪz feɪs ðət spaɪɪŋ wɑz ə waɪfs bɪznəs. ə mæn niɾəd tə lɪsən hɑɹd wən i θɔɾ ɪz waɪf wɑz dʒoʊkɪŋ; ʃi maɪt nɑt bi. ðə hoʊl noʊʃən ə spaɪɪŋ meɪɾ ɪm ənkʌmftəɹbəl, bʌɾ ɪf feɪl kəd juz əm soʊ, ðən soʊ kəɾ əɹ hʌzbənd, wən ðəɹ wɑz nid. dʒʌs ðə tu, ðoʊ. mæsimə sim kənvɪns ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp dɑɹkfɹɛnz wɝ feɪɾɪd tə fɑloʊ hɪm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, jɛɾ i maɪt ɡɹoʊ səspɪʃəs ɪf tu mɛni lɛf pɛɹɪnz kæmp tə dʒɔɪn hɪm.

Faile had used the lot of them for eyes-and-ears, a fact that still irritated him for some reason, though she had told him to his face that spying was a wife's business. A man needed to listen hard when he thought his wife was joking; she might not be. The whole notion of spying made him uncomfortable, but if Faile could use them so, then so could her husband, when there was need. Just the two, though. Masema seemed convinced that everyone except Darkfriends were fated to follow him sooner or later, yet he might grow suspicious if too many left Perrin's camp to join him.

"doʊn kɔl ɪm mæsimə, nɑɾ ivən hɪɹ," hi æɾəd bɹʌskli.

"Don't call him Masema, not even here," he added brusquely.

leɪtli ðə mæn kleɪmd mæsimə dɑɡɝ wɑz æktʃəli  dɛɾ ən ɹɪzən fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv əz ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən i wɑz tʌtʃiɝ ðən ɛvɝ əbaʊt mɛnʃən ə hɪz fɔɹmɝ neɪm.

Lately the man claimed Masema Dagar was actually dead and risen from the grave as the Prophet of the Lord Dragon Reborn, and he was touchier than ever about mention of his former name.

"ju ɡɛt kɛɹləs wɪð jəɹ tʌŋ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ pleɪs, ən jə maɪt bi lʌki ɪf i dʒʌst əz ə fju ʌv ɪz bʊlɪbɔɪz flɑɡ jə ðə nɛks taɪm ðeɪ kən faɪn jə əloʊn." sɛlənd nɑɾəd əɡɛn, ɡɹeɪvli, ən ðɪs taɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛni fɪɹ smɛl. laɪt, ðoʊz ɪɾiəts ə feɪlz læk ðə sɛns tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz wʌt ðeɪ ʃəd bi əfɹeɪɾ ʌv. "ɪts ɔlmoʊs dɔn," beɪlwɝ mɝmɝd, ʃɪvɝɪŋ ən pʊlɪŋ ɪz kloʊk taɪɾɝ. "ɔl wɪl bi weɪkɪŋ bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ən səm mæɾɝz ɑɹ bɛs dɪskʌst ənsin. ɪf maɪ leɪɾi wɪl kəntɪnju?" wʌns əɡɛn, ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə sədʒɛstʃən. sɛlən ən ðə ɹɛst ə feɪlz hæŋɝz-ɑn hæd bɪn ɡʊɾ oʊnli fəɹ kɑzɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl, ðət pɛɹɪn kəd si, ən beɪlwɝ lʊk tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ ə flaɪ ʌp əɹ noʊz fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt ʃi æktʃəli  ɡeɪv ən ɪmbɛɹəst stɑɹɾ ən mɝmɝɾ ən əpɑlədʒi.

"You get careless with your tongue in the wrong place, and you might be lucky if he just has a few of his bullyboys flog you the next time they can find you alone." Selande nodded again, gravely, and this time without any fear smell. Light, those idiots of Faile's lacked the sense to recognize what they should be afraid of. "It's almost dawn," Balwer murmured, shivering and pulling his cloak tighter. "All will be waking before long, and some matters are best discussed unseen. If my Lady will continue?" Once again, that was more than a suggestion. Selande and the rest of Faile's hangers-on had been good only for causing trouble, that Perrin could see, and Balwer looked to be trying to put a fly up her nose for some reason, but she actually gave an embarrassed start and murmured an apology.

ðə dɑɹknəs tʃɹuli wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə lɛsən, pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪzd, ət lis tə hɪz aɪz. ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd stɪl lʊk blæk, dʌstɪd wɪð bɹaɪt stɑɹz, jɛɾ i kəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪk aʊt ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə sɪks θɪn stʃɹaɪps ðət kɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə sɛlənz koʊt. hi kəd tɛl wʌn fɹəm ənʌðɝ, ɛniweɪ. ðə ɹiləzeɪʃən ðəɾ i hæd slɛp leɪɾɝ ðən juʒəwəl meɪɾ ɪm ɡɹaʊl. hi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə ɡɪv ɪn tə wɪɹinəs, haʊɛvɝ taɪɝɾ i wɑz! hi niɾəd tə hɪɹ sɛlənz ɹipɔɹt - ʃi wəd nɑt bi wɝiɾ əbaʊt mæsimə sɛndɪŋ aʊt ɹaɪɾɝz; ðə mæn dɪd ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi deɪ - jɛɾ i lʊkt æŋkʃəsli fəɹ ɛɹæm ən stɛpɝ. hɪz ɪɹz pɪkt ʌp ðə saʊnz ʌv æktɪvəɾi əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə hɪz hɔɹs jɛt.

The darkness truly was beginning to lessen, Perrin realized, at least to his eyes. The sky overhead still looked black, dusted with bright stars, yet he could almost make out the colors of the six thin stripes that crossed the front of Selande's coat. He could tell one from another, anyway. The realization that he had slept later than usual made him growl. He could not afford to give in to weariness, however tired he was! He needed to hear Selande's report - she would not be worried about Masema sending out riders; the man did that almost every day - yet he looked anxiously for Aram and Stepper. His ears picked up the sounds of activity among the horselines, but there was no sign of his horse yet.

"ðə sɛkən θɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd," sɛlən sɛd, "ɪz ðət hɑviɑɹ əz sin kæsks ə sɔl fɪʃ ən sɔl bif bɹændɪd wɪð ɔltɑɹən mɑɹkɪŋz, ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ʌv ðɛm. hi sɛz ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔltɑɹənz əmʌŋ mɑz . . .

"The second thing, my Lord," Selande said, "is that Haviar has seen casks of salt fish and salt beef branded with Altaran markings, a great many of them. He says there are Altarans among Mas . . .

əmʌŋ ðə pɹɑfəts pipəl, tu. sɛvɹəl əpɪɹ tə bi kɹæftsfoʊk, ən wʌn əɹ tu kəd bi mɝtʃəns əɹ taʊn əfɪʃəlz. ɪstæblɪʃt mɛn ən wɪmən, ɪn ɛni keɪs, sɑləd foʊk, ən səm sim ənʃʊɹ ðeɪ meɪd ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən. ə fju kwɛstʃənz maɪt ɹɪvil fɹəm wɛɹ ðə fɪʃ ən bif keɪm. ən pɝhæps ɡeɪn mɔɹ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz fəɹ ju."

among the Prophet's people, too. Several appear to be craftsfolk, and one or two could be merchants or town officials. Established men and women, in any case, solid folk, and some seem unsure they made the right decision. A few questions might reveal from where the fish and beef came. And perhaps gain more eyes-and-ears for you."

"aɪ noʊ wɛɹ ðə fɪʃ ən bif keɪm fɹəm ən soʊ də ju," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. hɪz hænz nɑɾɪd ɪndə fɪsts bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. hi hæd hoʊp ðə spid wɪð wɪtʃ i wɑz muvɪŋ wəd kip mæsimə fɹəm sɛndɪŋ aʊt ɹeɪɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz. ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ən əz bæɾ əz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪf nɑt wɝs. ðeɪ ɔfɝd pipəl ə tʃæns tə swɛɹ tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ðoʊz u ɹəfjuzd, səmtaɪmz ðoʊz u sɪmpli hɛzɪteɪɾɪd tu lɔŋ, daɪd baɪ faɪɝ ən stil. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt ɔf tə fɑloʊ mæsimə, ðoʊz u swɔɹ wɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə doʊneɪt dʒɛnɝəsli ɪn səpɔɹɾ ə ðə pɹɑfəts kɑz, waɪl ðoʊz u daɪd wɝ pleɪnli dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz fɔɹfɪt. θivz lɔst ə hænd, baɪ mæsiməz lɔz, bʌt nʌn ʌv wʌɾ ɪz ɹeɪɾɝz dɪd wɑz θivɪŋ, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə mæsimə. baɪ hɪz lɔz, mɝɾɝ ən ə hoʊl hoʊst ʌv ʌðɝ kɹaɪmz mɛɹɪɾɪd hæŋɪŋ, jɛɾ ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz sim tə pɹəfɝ kɪlɪŋ tə ɹəsivɪŋ oʊðz. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ lut, ðət weɪ, ən fəɹ səm ə ðɛm mɝɾɝ wɑz ə faɪn ɡeɪm tə pleɪ bɪfɔɹ iɾɪŋ.

"I know where the fish and beef came from and so do you," Perrin said irritably. His hands knotted into fists behind his back. He had hoped the speed with which he was moving would keep Masema from sending out raiding parties. That was what they were, and as bad as the Shaido if not worse. They offered people a chance to swear to the Dragon Reborn, and those who refused, sometimes those who simply hesitated too long, died by fire and steel. In any case, whether or not they marched off to follow Masema, those who swore were expected to donate generously in support of the Prophet's cause, while those who died were plainly Darkfriends, their belongings forfeit. Thieves lost a hand, by Masema's laws, but none of what his raiders did was thieving, according to Masema. By his laws, murder and a whole host of other crimes merited hanging, yet a fair number of his followers seemed to prefer killing to receiving oaths. There was more loot, that way, and for some of them murder was a fine game to play before eating.

"tɛl əm tə kip klɪɹ ə ðiz ɔltɑɹənz," pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn. "ɔl sɔɹts dʒɹɪft ɪndə mæsiməz fɑloʊɪŋ, ən ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ hævɪŋ sɛkən θɔts, ɪt woʊn teɪk əm lɔŋ tə stɪŋk ə zil laɪk ðə ɹɛst. ðeɪ wʊdn hɛzəteɪt tə ɡʌɾ ə neɪbɝ ðɛn, mʌtʃ lɛs sʌmbɑɾi huz æsk ðə ɹɔŋ kwɛstʃənz. wʌɾ aɪ wɑnə noʊ ɪz wʌt mæsiməz duɪŋ, wʌt hiz plænɪŋ." ðət ðə mæn hæd səm skim simd ɑbviəs. mæsimə kleɪmd ɪt wɑz blæsfəmi fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt ɹænd tə tʌtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, kleɪmd i wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə dʒɔɪn ɹænd ɪn ði ist. əz ɔlweɪz, θɔɾ ə ɹænd bɹɔt kʌlɝz wɝlɪŋ θɹu pɛɹɪnz hɛd, mɔɹ vɪvədli ðən juʒəwəl ðɪs taɪm, bʌɾ æŋɡɝ mɛltəɾ əm tə veɪpɝ. blæsfəmi əɹ noʊ, mæsimə hæɾ æksɛptɪd tʃɹævlɪŋ, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt dʒʌs tʃænəlɪŋ bʌt mɛn tʃænəlɪŋ. ən noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ i kleɪmd, hi hæd dʌn ɪt tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə wɛst əz lɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl, nɑt tə hɛlp ɹɛskju feɪl. pɛɹɪn tɛndəd tə tʃɹʌs pipəl əntɪl ðeɪ pɹuvd ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl, bʌt wʌn snɪf ə mæsimə hæd toʊld ɪm ðə fɛloʊ wɑz əz ɪnseɪn əz ə ɹæbɪɾ ænəməl ən lɛs tʃɹʌstwɝði. hi hæd kənsɪɾɝd weɪz tə stɑp ðət skim, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz.

"Tell them to keep clear of these Altarans," Perrin went on. "All sorts drift into Masema's following, and even if they are having second thoughts, it won't take them long to stink of zeal like the rest. They wouldn't hesitate to gut a neighbor then, much less somebody who's asked the wrong questions. What I want to know is what Masema's doing, what he's planning." That the man had some scheme seemed obvious. Masema claimed it was blasphemy for anyone except Rand to touch the One Power, claimed he wanted nothing more than to join Rand in the east. As always, thought of Rand brought colors whirling through Perrin's head, more vividly than usual this time, but anger melted them to vapor. Blasphemy or no, Masema had accepted Traveling, which was not just channeling but men channeling. And no matter what he claimed, he had done it to remain in the west as long as possible, not to help rescue Faile. Perrin tended to trust people until they proved unreliable, but one sniff of Masema had told him the fellow was as insane as a rabid animal and less trustworthy. He had considered ways to stop that scheme, whatever it was.

weɪz tə stɑp mæsiməz kɪlɪŋ ən bɝnɪŋ. mæsimə hæd tɛn əɹ twɛlv θaʊzən mɛn wɪð hɪm, meɪbi mɔɹ - ðə mæn wɑz nɑt vɛɹi fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ əbaʊt nʌmbɝz, ən ðə weɪ ðeɪ kæmpt ɪn ə skwɑləd spɹɔl meɪd kaʊntɪŋ ɪmpɑsəbəl - waɪl lɛs ðən ə kɔɹɾɝ ə ðət nʌmbɝ fɑloʊd pɛɹɪn, sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ɡɹumz ən ʌðɝz u wəd bi mɔɹ hɪnʒɹəns ðən hɛlp ɪn ə faɪt, jɛt wɪð θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ən tu æʃəmən, nɑt tə mɛnʃən sɪks il waɪz wʌnz, hi kəd hɔl mæsimə ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks. ðə waɪz wʌnz ən tu ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi iɡɝ tə teɪk pɑɹt. mɔɹ ðən sɪmpli wɪlɪŋ, ət list. ðeɪ wɑntəd mæsimə dɛd. bʌt dɪspɝsɪŋ mæsiməz ɑɹmi wəɾ oʊnli bɹeɪk ɪɾ ɪndə hʌnʒɹədz ə smɔlɝ bænz ðət wəd skæɾɝ əkɹɔs ɔltɑɹə ən bɪɑnd, stɪl luɾɪŋ ən kɪlɪŋ, dʒʌs fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɪl də ðə seɪm θɪŋ, hi θɔt, ən pʊʃt ðə θɔɾ əweɪ. stɑpɪŋ mæsimə wəd teɪk taɪm i dɪd nɑt hæv. ðə mæn wəɾ əv tə kip əntɪl feɪl wɑz seɪf. əntɪl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ smæʃt tə kɪnlɪŋ. "wʌts ðə θɝd θɪŋ jə lɝn tənaɪt, sɛlənd?" hi sɛd ɹʌfli. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ðə smɛl ʌv wɝi kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə wʊmən θɪkənd.

Ways to stop Masema's killing and burning. Masema had ten or twelve thousand men with him, maybe more - the man was not very forthcoming about numbers, and the way they camped in a squalid sprawl made counting impossible - while less than a quarter of that number followed Perrin, several hundred of them cart drivers and grooms and others who would be more hindrance than help in a fight, yet with three Aes Sedai and two Asha'man, not to mention six Aiel Wise Ones, he could halt Masema in his tracks. The Wise Ones and two of the Aes Sedai would be eager to take part. More than simply willing, at least. They wanted Masema dead. But dispersing Masema's army would only break it into hundreds of smaller bands that would scatter across Altara and beyond, still looting and killing, just for themselves instead of in the name of the Dragon Reborn. Breaking the Shaido will do the same thing, he thought, and pushed the thought away. Stopping Masema would take time he did not have. The man would have to keep until Faile was safe. Until the Shaido were smashed to kindling. "What's the third thing you learned tonight, Selande?" he said roughly. To his surprise, the smell of worry coming from the woman thickened.

"hɑviɑɹ sɔ sʌmwʌn," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "hi dɪd nɑt tɛl mi ət fɝst." hɝ vɔɪs hɑɹɾənd fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ ðət wɪl nɑt hæpən əɡɛn!" dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi sim tə stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð hɝsɛlf, ðən bɝst aʊt, "mɑsʊɝi sədaɪ hæz vɪzəɾəd mæsimə . . . ðə pɹɑfət. ɪts tʃɹu, maɪ lɔɹd; bɪliv mi! hɑviɑɹ əz sin əɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ʃi slɪps ɪndə ðɛɹ kæmp hʊɾɪd ən livz ðə seɪm weɪ, bʌt hiz hæɾ ə ɡʊd lʊk əɾ əɹ feɪs twaɪs. ə mæn əkʌmpəniz əɹ itʃ taɪm, ən səmtaɪmz ənʌðɝ wʊmən. hɑviɑɹ əz nɑt sin ðə mæn wɛl ɪnʌf tə bi ʃʊɹ, bʌt ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən fɪts ɹoʊvɛɹ, mɑsʊɝiz wɔɹɾɝ, ən hɑviɑɹ ɪz sɝɾən ðə sɛkənd wʊmən ɪz ənʊɹə sədaɪ." ʃi bɹoʊk ɔf əbɹʌpli, hɝ aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ dɑɹkli ɪn ðə munlaɪɾ əz ʃi wɑtʃt hɪm. laɪt, ʃi wɑz əz wɝiɾ əbaʊt haʊ hi wəd teɪk ɪɾ əz baɪ wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt! hi fɔɹst ɪz hænz tə ənklɛntʃ.

"Haviar saw someone," she said slowly. "He did not tell me at first." Her voice hardened for a moment. "I made sure that will not happen again!" Drawing a deep breath, she seemed to struggle with herself, then burst out, "Masuri Sedai has visited Masema . . . the Prophet. It is true, my Lord; believe me! Haviar has seen her more than once. She slips into their camp hooded and leaves the same way, but he has had a good look at her face twice. A man accompanies her each time, and sometimes another woman. Haviar has not seen the man well enough to be sure, but the description fits Rovair, Masuri's Warder, and Haviar is certain the second woman is Annoura Sedai." She broke off abruptly, her eyes shining darkly in the moonlight as she watched him. Light, she was as worried about how he would take it as by what it meant! He forced his hands to unclench.

mæsimə dɪspaɪzd ɛɛs sədaɪ əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd dɑɹkfɹɛnz; hi nɪɹli kənsɪɾɝd əm dɑɹkfɹɛnz. soʊ waɪ wəɾ i ɹəsiv tu sɪstɝz? waɪ wəd ðeɪ ɡoʊ tə hɪm? ənʊɹəz əpɪnjən ə mæsimə leɪ hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ mɪstɝi ən dʌbəldʒɔɪntɪd kɑmɛns ðət kəd min ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt mɑsʊɝi hæd sɛd stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt ðət ðə mæn niɾəd tə bi pʊt daʊn laɪk ə mæd dɔɡ.

Masema despised Aes Sedai as much as he did Darkfriends; he nearly considered them Darkfriends. So why would he receive two sisters? Why would they go to him? Annoura's opinion of Masema lay hidden behind Aes Sedai mystery and doublejointed comments that could mean anything, but Masuri had said straight out that the man needed to be put down like a mad dog.

"meɪk ʃʊɹ hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən kip ə ʃɑɹp aɪ fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz ən si ɪf ðeɪ kən ivzdʒɹɑp ɑn wʌn ə ðɛɹ miɾɪŋz wɪð mæsimə." kəd hɑviɑɹ bi mɪsteɪkən? noʊ, ðəɹ wɝ fju wɪmən ɪn mæsiməz kæmp, ɹɛləɾɪvli spikɪŋ, ən ɪt pæs bɪlif ðət ðə tɛɹən kəd mɪsteɪk wʌn ə ðoʊz ənwɑʃt mɝɾɝəs-aɪd hɛɹɹəɾənz fəɹ mɑsʊɝi. ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wɪmən wɪlɪŋ tə mɑɹtʃ wɪð mæsimə juʒəwəli meɪd ðə mɛn lʊk laɪk tɪŋkɝz. "tɛl əm tə teɪk kɛɹ, ðoʊ. bɛɾɝ tə lɛt ðə tʃæns pæs ðən ɡɛt kɑɾ əɾ ɪt. ðəɹ noʊ ɡʊd tə ɛniwʌn stʃɹʌŋ ʌp ɑn ə tʃɹi." pɛɹɪn nu hi saʊndəd ɡɹʌf, ən tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs maɪldɝ. ðət sim hɑɹɾɝ sɪns feɪl wɑz kɪdnæpt. "juv dʌn wɛl, sɛlənd." ət list i dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf i wɝ bɑɹkɪŋ ət hɝ. "ju ən hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən. feɪl wəd bi pɹaʊɾ ɪf ʃi nu."

"Make sure Haviar and Nerion keep a sharp eye for the sisters and see if they can eavesdrop on one of their meetings with Masema." Could Haviar be mistaken? No, there were few women in Masema's camp, relatively speaking, and it passed belief that the Tairen could mistake one of those unwashed murderous-eyed harridans for Masuri. The sort of women willing to march with Masema usually made the men look like Tinkers. "Tell them to take care, though. Better to let the chance pass than get caught at it. They're no good to anyone strung up on a tree." Perrin knew he sounded gruff, and tried to make his voice milder. That seemed harder since Faile was kidnapped. "You've done well, Selande." At least he did not sound as if he were barking at her. "You and Haviar and Nerion. Faile would be proud if she knew."

ə smaɪl lɪɾ ʌp əɹ feɪs, ən ʃi stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl stʃɹeɪɾɝ, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. pɹaɪd, klin ən bɹaɪt, ðə pɹaɪɾ ʌv əkɑmplɪʃmənt, ɔlmoʊst oʊvɝwɛlmd ɛni ʌðɝ sɛn fɹəm hɝ! "θæŋk ju, maɪ lɔɹd. θæŋk ju!" jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ə pɹaɪz. meɪbi hi hæd, kʌm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt.

A smile lit up her face, and she stood a little straighter, if that was possible. Pride, clean and bright, the pride of accomplishment, almost overwhelmed any other scent from her! "Thank you, my Lord. Thank you!" You would have thought he had given her a prize. Maybe he had, come to think on it.

ðoʊ kʌm tə θɪŋk feɪl maɪt nɑt bi bɛs pliz ðəɾ i wɑz juzɪŋ əɹ aɪz-ændɪɹz, əɹ ivən nu əbaʊt ðɛm. wʌns, ðə θɔɾ ə feɪl dɪsplizd wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm ənizi, bʌt ðət wɑz bɪfɔɹ i lɝn əbaʊɾ əɹ spaɪz. ən ðət lɪɾəl mæɾɝ ə ðə bɹoʊkən kɹaʊn ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs hæd lɛt slɪp. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɔlweɪz sɛd ðət waɪvz kɛp ðɛɹ sikɹəts kloʊs, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ lɪməts! ədʒʌstɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɑn ɪz nɛɹoʊ ʃoʊldɝz wɪð wʌn hænd, beɪlwɝ kɔf bɪhaɪn ði ʌðɝ. "wɛl sɛd, maɪ lɔɹd. vɛɹi wɛl sɛd. maɪ leɪɾi, aɪm ʃʊɹ jə wɑnə pæs ɑn lɔɹd pɛɹɪnz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ɪt wʊdn də fəɹ ðəɹ tə bi ɛni mɪsəndɝstændɪŋ." sɛlənd nɑɾəd wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz ɔf pɛɹɪn. hɝ maʊθ oʊpənd, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt hoʊpɪŋ i faʊnd wɔɾɝ ən ʃeɪd.

Though come to think Faile might not be best pleased that he was using her eyes-andears, or even knew about them. Once, the thought of Faile displeased would have made him uneasy, but that was before he learned about her spies. And that little matter of the Broken Crown that Elyas had let slip. Everybody always said that wives kept their secrets close, but there were limits! Adjusting his cloak on his narrow shoulders with one hand, Balwer coughed behind the other. "Well said, my Lord. Very well said. My Lady, I'm sure you want to pass on Lord Perrin's instructions as soon as possible. It wouldn't do for there to be any misunderstanding." Selande nodded without taking her eyes off Perrin. Her mouth opened, and Perrin was sure she intended to say something about hoping he found water and shade.

laɪt, wɔɾɝ wɑz ðə wʌn θɪŋ ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn plɛnti, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz moʊsli fɹoʊzən, ən ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, noʊbɑdi niɾəd ʃeɪɾ ivən ət nun! ʃi pɹɑbli dɪɾ ɪntɛn ɪt, kəz ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪf aɪ meɪ bi soʊ boʊld, ɡɹeɪs əz feɪvɝd ðə leɪɾi feɪl ɪn ju." pɛɹɪn dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ə nɑɾ ə θæŋks. ðəɹ wɑz ə teɪst ʌv æʃəz ɪn ɪz maʊθ. ɡɹeɪs hæɾ ə fʌni weɪ ʌv feɪvɝɪŋ feɪl, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə hʌzbən u stɪl hæd nɑt faʊn əɹ æftɝ mɔɹ ðən tu wiks ə sɝtʃɪŋ. ðə meɪɾənz sɛd ʃi hæd bɪn meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn, ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi mɪstʃɹiɾɪd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd tə ədmɪt ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd bɹoʊkən ðɛɹ kʌstəmz ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹənt weɪz. ɪn ɪz bʊk, biɪŋ kɪdnæpt wɑz mɪstʃɹitmən ɪnʌf. bɪɾɝ æʃəz.

Light, water was the one thing they had in plenty, even if it was mostly frozen, and this time of year, nobody needed shade even at noon! She probably did intend it, because she hesitated before saying, "Grace favor you, my Lord. If I may be so bold, Grace has favored the Lady Faile in you." Perrin jerked his head in a nod of thanks. There was a taste of ashes in his mouth. Grace had a funny way of favoring Faile, giving her a husband who still had not found her after more than two weeks of searching. The Maidens said she had been made gai'shain, that she would not be mistreated, but they had to admit these Shaido already had broken their customs a hundred different ways. In his book, being kidnapped was mistreatment enough. Bitter ashes.

"ðə leɪɾi wɪl də vɛɹi wɛl, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛd sɔfli, wɑtʃɪŋ sɛlən vænɪʃ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs əmʌŋ ðə kɑɹts. ðɪs əpɹuvəl wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz; hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk pɛɹɪn aʊɾ ə juzɪŋ sɛlən ən əɹ fɹɛnz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnz ðeɪ wɝ hɑthɛɾəd ən ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl. "ʃi hæz ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɪnstɪŋks.

"The lady will do very well, my Lord," Balwer said softly, watching Selande vanish into the darkness among the carts. This approval was a surprise; he had tried to talk Perrin out of using Selande and her friends on the grounds they were hotheaded and unreliable. "She has the necessary instincts.

kɛɹhinɪn du, juʒəwəli, ən tɛɹənz tə səm ɪkstɛnt, ət lis ðə noʊbəlz, ɪspɛʃli wʌns - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli, ən aɪd pɛɹɪn kɔʃəsli. ɪf i wɝ ənʌðɝ mæn, pɛɹɪn wʊɾə bɪlivd i hæd sɛd mɔɹ ðən i ɪntɛndəd, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd beɪlwɝ slɪpt ɪn ðət fæʃən. ðə mænz sɛn ɹɪmeɪn stɛɾi, nɑt dʒɪɡəlɪŋ ðə weɪ ɪt wəɾ ɪn ə mæn u wɑz ənʃʊɹ. "meɪ aɪ ɔfɝ wʌn əɹ tu pɔɪns ɑn əɹ ɹipɔɹt, maɪ lɔɹd?"

Cairhienin do, usually, and Tairens to some extent, at least the nobles, especially once - " He cut off abruptly, and eyed Perrin cautiously. If he were another man, Perrin would have believed he had said more than he intended, but he doubted Balwer slipped in that fashion. The man's scent remained steady, not jiggling the way it would in a man who was unsure. "May I offer one or two points on her report, my Lord?"

ðə kɹʌntʃ ə hʊvz ɪn ðə snoʊ ənaʊns ði əpɹoʊtʃ ʌv ɛɹæm, liɾɪŋ pɛɹɪnz dʌn stæljən ən ɪz oʊn ɹeɪnʒi ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ. ðə tu ænəməlz wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə nɪp ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən ɛɹæm wɑz kipɪŋ əm wɛl əpɑɹt, ðoʊ wɪð səm dɪfəkəlti. beɪlwɝ saɪd.

The crunch of hooves in the snow announced the approach of Aram, leading Perrin's dun stallion and his own rangy gray gelding. The two animals were trying to nip at one another, and Aram was keeping them well apart, though with some difficulty. Balwer sighed.

"ju kən seɪ wʌtɛvɝ jə nid tə ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɹæm, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. ðə lɪɾəl mæn baʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ækwiɛsəns, bʌɾ i saɪɾ əɡɛn, tu. ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə kæmp nu ðət beɪlwɝ hæd ðə skɪl ə fɪɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ɹumɝz ən tʃæns-hɝd kɑmɛns ən θɪŋz pipəl hæd dʌn tə fɔɹm ə pɪktʃɝ ʌv wʌt hæd ɹɪli hæpən əɹ wʌt maɪt, ən beɪlwɝ hɪmsɛlf kənsɪɾɝd ðət pɑɹɾ ə hɪz dʒɑb əz ə sɛkɹətɛɹi, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən i laɪk tə pɹitɛn i nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɛni sətʃ θɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə hɑɹmləs pɹitɛns, ən pɛɹɪn tɛndəd tə hjumɝ hɪm.

"You can say whatever you need to in front of Aram, Master Balwer," Perrin said. The little man bowed his head in acquiescence, but he sighed again, too. Everybody in the camp knew that Balwer had the skill of fitting together rumors and chance-heard comments and things people had done to form a picture of what had really happened or what might, and Balwer himself considered that part of his job as a secretary, but for some reason he liked to pretend he never did any such thing. It was a harmless pretense, and Perrin tended to humor him.

teɪkɪŋ stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz fɹəm ɛɹæm, hi sɛd, "wɔk bɪhaɪn əs əwaɪl, ɛɹæm. aɪ nid tə tɔk wɪð mæstɝ beɪlwɝ ɪn pɹaɪvət." beɪlwɝz saɪ wɑz soʊ feɪn ðət pɛɹɪn bɛɹli hɝɾ ɪt.

Taking Stepper's reins from Aram, he said, "Walk behind us awhile, Aram. I need to talk with Master Balwer in private." Balwer's sigh was so faint that Perrin barely heard it.

ɛɹæm fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn ðə tu ʌv əm wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝɾ əz ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə wɔk, fɹoʊzən snoʊ kɹækɪŋ bɪniθ ðɛɹ fit, bʌɾ ɪz sɛnt ɡɹu spaɪki əɡɛn, ən kwɪvɝi, ə θɪn, saʊɝ smɛl. ðɪs taɪm, pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə sɛnt, ðoʊ hi peɪɾ ɪt noʊ mɔɹ maɪn ðən juʒəwəl. ɛɹæm wɑz dʒɛləs ʌv ɛniwʌn ɪksɛp feɪl u spɛn taɪm wɪð hɪm. pɛɹɪn sɔ noʊ weɪ tə pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ɪt, ən ɛniweɪ, hi wɑz əz juz tə ɛɹæmz pəzɛsɪvnəs əz i wɑz tə ðə weɪ beɪlwɝ hɑpt əlɔŋ əɾ ɪz saɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə si wɛðɝ ɛɹæm wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ wən i faɪnəli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə spik. beɪlwɝz ɹeɪzɝ-θɪn sɛn ə səspɪʃən, kjʊɹiəsli dʒɹaɪ ən nɑɾ ivən wɔɹm bʌt stɪl səspɪʃən, pɹəvaɪɾəd ə kaʊntɝpɔɪn tə ɛɹæmz dʒɛləsi. jə kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ mɛn u dɪd nɑt wɑnə tʃeɪnʒ. ðə hɔɹslaɪnz ən səplaɪ kɑɹts wɝ loʊkeɪɾəd ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kæmp, wɛɹ θivz wəɾ əv ə hɑɹd taɪm ɹitʃɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɔlðoʊ ðə skaɪ stɪl lʊk blæk tə moʊst aɪz, ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ɡɹumz, hu slɛp kloʊs tə ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz, wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi əweɪk ən foʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ blæŋkəts, səm tɛndɪŋ ʃɛltɝz meɪɾ ə paɪn baʊz ən ʌðɝ smɔl tʃɹi lɪmz hɑɹvəstəd fɹəm ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ fɔɹəst, ɪn keɪs ðeɪ maɪt bi niɾəd ənʌðɝ naɪt.

Aram fell in behind the two of them without a word as they began to walk, frozen snow cracking beneath their feet, but his scent grew spiky again, and quivery, a thin, sour smell. This time, Perrin recognized the scent, though he paid it no more mind than usual. Aram was jealous of anyone except Faile who spent time with him. Perrin saw no way to put a stop to it, and anyway, he was as used to Aram's possessiveness as he was to the way Balwer hopped along at his side, glancing over his shoulder to see whether Aram was close enough to hear when he finally decided to speak. Balwer's razor-thin scent of suspicion, curiously dry and not even warm but still suspicion, provided a counterpoint to Aram's jealousy. You could not change men who did not want to change. The horselines and supply carts were located in the middle of the camp, where thieves would have a hard time reaching them, and although the sky still looked black to most eyes, the cart drivers and grooms, who slept close to their charges, were already awake and folding their blankets, some tending shelters made of pine boughs and other small tree limbs harvested from the surrounding forest, in case they might be needed another night.

kʊk faɪɝz wɝ biɪŋ lɪɾ ən smɔl blæk kɛɾəlz sɛɾ oʊvɝ ðɛm, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl tə iɾ ɪksɛpt pɔɹədʒ əɹ dʒɹaɪd binz. hʌntɪŋ ən tʃɹæpɪŋ æɾəd səm mit, vɛnəsən ən ɹæbəts, pɑɹtʃɹɪdʒɪz ən wʊdhənz ən ðə laɪk, bʌt ðət kəɾ oʊnli ɡoʊ soʊ fɑɹ wɪð soʊ mɛni tə fid, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊwɛɹ tə baɪ səplaɪz sɪns bɪfɔɹ kɹɔsɪŋ ði ɪldɑɹ. ə ɹɪpəl ə baʊz ən kɝtsiz ən mɝmɝz ʌv "ə ɡʊd mɔɹnɪŋ, maɪ lɔɹd" ən "ðə laɪt feɪvɝ ju, maɪ lɔɹd" fɑloʊd pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðə mɛn ən wɪmən u sɔ hɪm stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʃɹɛŋθən ðɛɹ ʃɛltɝz, ən ə fju bɪɡæn tə pʊl ðɛɹz daʊn, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd sɛnst ɪz dɪtɝməneɪʃən fɹəm ɪz stʃɹaɪd. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn ɪz ɹizɑlv baɪ naʊ. sɪns ðə deɪ hi ɹilaɪz haʊ bædli hi hæd blʌndɝd, hi hæd nɑt spɛn tu naɪts ɪn wʌn pleɪs. hi ɹɪtɝn ðə ɡɹiɾɪŋz wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə kæmp meɪɾ ə θɪn ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə hɔɹsəz ən kɑɹts, feɪsɪŋ ði ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ fɔɹəst, wɪð ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə fɔɹ ɡɹups ən ðə lænsɝz fɹəm ɡildən ən min speɪs bɪtwin ðɛm. huɛvɝ keɪm ət ðɛm, fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ dɝɛkʃən, wəd feɪs tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊz ən tʃɹeɪn kævəlɹi.

Cook fires were being lit and small black kettles set over them, though there was little to eat except porridge or dried beans. Hunting and trapping added some meat, venison and rabbits, partridges and woodhens and the like, but that could only go so far with so many to feed, and there had been nowhere to buy supplies since before crossing the Eldar. A ripple of bows and curtsies and murmurs of "A good morning, my Lord" and "The Light favor you, my Lord" followed Perrin, but the men and women who saw him stopped trying to strengthen their shelters, and a few began to pull theirs down, as though they had sensed his determination from his stride. They should have known his resolve by now. Since the day he realized how badly he had blundered, he had not spent two nights in one place. He returned the greetings without slowing. The rest of the camp made a thin ring around the horses and carts, facing the encircling forest, with the Two Rivers men divided into four groups and the lancers from Ghealdan and Mayene spaced between them. Whoever came at them, from whatever direction, would face Two Rivers longbows and trained cavalry.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə sʌɾən əpɪɹəns baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ðət pɛɹɪn fɪɹd, bʌt ɹæðɝ mæsimə. ðə mæn sim tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm mikli ɪnʌf, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðɪs nuz ə ɹeɪɾɪŋ, naɪn ɡildænɪn ən eɪt minɝz hæd vænɪʃt ɪn ðə læs tu wiks, ən noʊ wʌn bɪliv ðeɪ hæd dɪzɝɾɪd. bɪfɔɹ ðæt, ɑn ðə deɪ feɪl wɑz stoʊlən, twɛnti minɝz hæd bɪn æmbʊʃt ən kɪld, ən noʊ wʌn bɪlivd ɪt hæd bɪn ɛniwʌn bʌt mæsiməz mɛn u dɪd ðə kɪlɪŋ. soʊ ən ənizi pis ɪɡzɪstəd, ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɔɹni sɔɹɾ ə pis, jɛɾ ə kɑpɝ weɪdʒɝɾ ɑn ɪt læstɪŋ fɝɛvɝ wɑz laɪkli ə kɑpɝ lɔst. mæsimə pɹitɛndəd tə bi ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv ɛni deɪnʒɝ tə ðət pis, bʌɾ ɪz fɑloʊɝz sim nɑt tə kɛɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ði ʌðɝ, ən wʌtɛvɝ mæsimə pɹitɛndəd, ðeɪ tʊk ðɛɹ lɛd fɹəm hɪm. sʌmhaʊ, ðoʊ, pɛɹɪn ɪntɛndəd tə si ðəɾ ɪɾ ɛndʒjʊɹɾ əntɪl feɪl wɑz fɹi. meɪkɪŋ ɪz oʊn kæmp tu tʌf ə nʌt tə kɹæk wɑz wʌn weɪ ʌv meɪkɪŋ ðə pis læst.

It was not a sudden appearance by the Shaido that Perrin feared, but rather Masema. The man seemed to be following him meekly enough, but aside from this news of raiding, nine Ghealdanin and eight Mayeners had vanished in the last two weeks, and no one believed they had deserted. Before that, on the day Faile was stolen, twenty Mayeners had been ambushed and killed, and no one believed it had been anyone but Masema's men who did the killing. So an uneasy peace existed, a strange thorny sort of peace, yet a copper wagered on it lasting forever was likely a copper lost. Masema pretended to be unaware of any danger to that peace, but his followers seemed not to care one way or the other, and whatever Masema pretended, they took their lead from him. Somehow, though, Perrin intended to see that it endured until Faile was free. Making his own camp too tough a nut to crack was one way of making the peace last.

ði il hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn hævɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn θɪn wɛdʒ ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ paɪ, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ ðən fɪfti ʌv ðɛm, kaʊntɪŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn u sɝv ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən i pɔz tə stʌɾi ðɛɹ loʊ dɑɹk tɛns. ði oʊnli ʌðɝ tɛns ɪɹɛktəɾ ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə kæmp wɝ ðoʊz ə bɹəleɪn ən əɹ tu sɝvɪŋ wɪmən, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm bɹaɪɾənz fju haʊsəz. fliz ən laɪs ɪn hɔɹdz meɪd ðoʊz ʌnɪnhæbəɾəbəl, ivən fəɹ hɑɹɾənd soʊlʒɝz sikɪŋ ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə koʊld, ən ðə bɑɹnz wɝ pjutʃɹɪd ɹæmʃækəl əfɛɹz ðət lɛt ðə wɪn haʊl θɹu ən hɑɹbɝd wɝs vɝmɪn ðən ðə haʊsəz.

The Aiel had insisted on having their own thin wedge of the strange pie, though there were fewer than fifty of them, counting the gai'shain who served the Wise Ones, and he paused to study their low dark tents. The only other tents erected anywhere in the camp were those of Berelain and her two serving women, on the other side of the camp, not far from Brytan's few houses. Fleas and lice in hordes made those uninhabitable, even for hardened soldiers seeking shelter from the cold, and the barns were putrid ramshackle affairs that let the wind howl through and harbored worse vermin than the houses.

ðə meɪɾənz ən ɡɔl, ði oʊnli mæn əmʌŋ ði il nɑt ɡeɪʃeɪn, wɝ ɔl aʊt wɪð ðə skaʊts, ən ði il tɛns wɝ saɪlən ən stɪl, ðoʊ ðə smɛl ə smoʊk kʌmɪŋ fɹəm səm ə ðə vɛn hoʊlz toʊld ɪm ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ pɹipɛɹɪŋ bɹɛkfəs fəɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz, əɹ sɝvɪŋ ɪt. ənʊɹə wɑz bɹəleɪnz ædvaɪzɝ, ən juʒəwəli ʃɛɹɾ əɹ tɛnt, bʌt mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪd wəd bi wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz, meɪbi ivən hɛlpɪŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪð bɹɛkfəst. ðeɪ stɪl tʃɹaɪd tə haɪd ðə fæk ðət ðə waɪz wʌnz kənsɪɾɝd əm əpɹɛntəsɪz, ðoʊ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn kæmp mʌs bi əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt baɪ naʊ. ɛniwʌn u sɔ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ æktʃəli  kæɹiɪŋ faɪɝwʊɾ əɹ wɔɾɝ, əɹ hɝd wʌn biɪŋ swɪtʃt, kəd meɪk ɪɾ aʊt. ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ oʊθswɔɹn tə ɹænd - əɡɛn ðə kʌlɝz wɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən ɪksploʊʒən ə hjuz; əɡɛn ðeɪ mɛltəɾ ʌndɝ ɪz kɑnstən æŋɡɝ - bʌɾ ɛdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz hæd bɪn sɛn tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ðɛm.

The Maidens and Gaul, the only man among the Aiel not gai'shain, were all out with the scouts, and the Aiel tents were silent and still, though the smell of smoke coming from some of the vent holes told him the gai'shain were preparing breakfast for the Wise Ones, or serving it. Annoura was Berelain's adviser, and usually shared her tent, but Masuri and Seonid would be with the Wise Ones, maybe even helping the gai'shain with breakfast. They still tried to hide the fact that the Wise Ones considered them apprentices, though everyone in camp must be aware of it by now. Anyone who saw an Aes Sedai actually carrying firewood or water, or heard one being switched, could make it out. The two Aes Sedai were oathsworn to Rand - again the colors whirled in his head, an explosion of hues; again they melted under his constant anger - but Edarra and the other Wise Ones had been sent to keep an eye on them.

oʊnli ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɛmsɛlvz nu haʊ taɪtli ðɛɹ oʊðz hɛl ðɛm, əɹ wʌt ɹum ðeɪ sɔ tə mənuvɝ bɪtwin ðə wɝdz, ən niðɝ wɑz əlaʊd tə hɑp ənlɛs ə waɪz wʌn sɛd toʊd.

Only the Aes Sedai themselves knew how tightly their oaths held them, or what room they saw to maneuver between the words, and neither was allowed to hop unless a Wise One said toad.

siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi hæd boʊθ sɛd mæsimə ʃəd bi pʊt daʊn laɪk ə mæd dɔɡ, ən ðə waɪz wʌnz əɡɹid. əɹ soʊ ðeɪ sɛd. ðeɪ hæd noʊ θɹi oʊðz tə hoʊld əm tə ðə tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ oʊθ hɛl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ mɔɹ ɪn lɛɾɝ ðən spɪɹət. ən i sim tə ɹikɔl wʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz tɛlɪŋ ɪm ðət mɑsʊɝi θɔt ðət ðə mæd dɔɡ kəd bi liʃt. nɑɾ əlaʊd tə hɑp ənlɛs ə waɪz wʌn sɛd toʊd. ɪt wɑz laɪk ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl wɪð ði ɛdʒəz ə ðə mɛɾəl pisəz ʃɑɹpənd. hi niɾəd tə sɑlv ɪt, bʌt wʌn mɪsteɪk ən i kəd kʌt hɪmsɛlf tə ðə boʊn. fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, pɛɹɪn kɑt beɪlwɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, lɪps pɝst ɪn θɔt. ə bɝd stʌɾiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʌnfəmɪljɝ, nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, nɑt hʌŋɡɹi, dʒʌs kjʊɹiəs. ɡæðɝɪŋ stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz, hi wɔkt ɑn soʊ kwɪkli ðət ðə lɪɾəl mæn hæd tə lɛŋθən ɪz stʃɹaɪɾ ɪndə smɔl dʒʌmps tə kætʃ ʌp.

Seonid and Masuri had both said Masema should be put down like a mad dog, and the Wise Ones agreed. Or so they said. They had no Three Oaths to hold them to the truth, though in truth, that particular Oath held the Aes Sedai more in letter than spirit. And he seemed to recall one of the Wise Ones telling him that Masuri thought that the mad dog could be leashed. Not allowed to hop unless a Wise One said toad. It was like a blacksmith's puzzle with the edges of the metal pieces sharpened. He needed to solve it, but one mistake and he could cut himself to the bone. From the corner of his eye, Perrin caught Balwer watching him, lips pursed in thought. A bird studying something unfamiliar, not afraid, not hungry, just curious. Gathering Stepper's reins, he walked on so quickly that the little man had to lengthen his stride into small jumps to catch up.

tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn hæd ðə sɛɡmən ə kæmp nɛks tə ði il, feɪsɪŋ nɔɹθist, ən pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝd wɔkɪŋ ə lɪɾəl nɔɹθ, tə wɛɹ ɡildænɪn lænsɝz wɝ kæmpt, əɹ saʊθ tə ðə nɪɹəs minɝ sɛkʃən, bʌt teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs θɹu hɪz fɹɛnz ən neɪbɝz fɹəm hoʊm. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl əweɪk, hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks ən fiɾɪŋ ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðɛɹ ʃɛltɝz ɪndə ðə kʊk faɪɝz əɹ kʌɾɪŋ ʌp ðə koʊld ɹɪmeɪnz ə læs naɪts ɹæbət tə æd tə ðə pɔɹədʒ ɪn ðə kɛɾəlz. tɔk dwɪndəld ən ðə smɛl ʌv wɛɹinɪs ɡɹu θɪk əz hɛdz lɪftəd tə wɑtʃ hɪm. wɛtstoʊnz pɔzd ɪn slaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ stil, ðən ɹɪzum ðɛɹ sɪbələnt wɪspɝɪŋ. ðə baʊ wɑz ðɛɹ pɹəfɝd wɛpən, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kæɹiɾ ə hɛvi dæɡɝ əɹ ə ʃɔɹt-sɔɹɾ əz wɛl, əɹ səmtaɪmz ə lɔŋzɔɝd, ən ðeɪ hæd pɪkt ʌp spɪɹz ən hælbɝdz ən ʌðɝ pɑlɹmz wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ bleɪdz ən pɔɪns ðət ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd nɑt θɔt wɝθ kæɹiɪŋ ɔf wɪð ðɛɹ pɪlɪdʒ. spɪɹz ðeɪ wɝ əkʌstəm tə, ən hænz juz tə wildɪŋ ðə kɔɹɾɝstæf ət fistdeɪ kɑmpətɪʃənz faʊn ðə pɑlɹmz nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹənt wʌns ðə weɪɾ ə mɛɾəl ɑn wʌn ɛnd wɑz əkaʊntəd fɔɹ. ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ hʌŋɡɹi, taɪɝɾ ən wɪθdʒɹɔn.

Two Rivers men had the segment of camp next to the Aiel, facing northeast, and Perrin considered walking a little north, to where Ghealdanin lancers were camped, or south to the nearest Mayener section, but taking a deep breath, he made himself lead his horse through his friends and neighbors from home. They were all awake, huddling in their cloaks and feeding the remnants of their shelters into the cook fires or cutting up the cold remains of last night's rabbit to add to the porridge in the kettles. Talk dwindled and the smell of wariness grew thick as heads lifted to watch him. Whetstones paused in sliding along steel, then resumed their sibilant whispering. The bow was their preferred weapon, but everyone carried a heavy dagger or a short-sword as well, or sometimes a longsword, and they had picked up spears and halberds and other polearms with strange blades and points that the Shaido had not thought worth carrying off with their pillage. Spears they were accustomed to, and hands used to wielding the quarterstaff at feastday competitions found the polearms not much different once the weight of metal on one end was accounted for. Their faces were hungry, tired and withdrawn.

sʌmwʌn ɹeɪzd ə hæfhɑɹɾɪd kɹaɪ ʌv "ɡoʊldeɪniz!" bʌt noʊ wʌn tʊk ɪɾ ʌp, ə θɪŋ ðət wʊɾə pliz pɛɹɪn ə mʌnθ ɡɔn. ə ɡɹeɪt dil hæd tʃeɪnʒd sɪns feɪl wɑz teɪkən. naʊ ðɛɹ saɪləns wɑz lɛɾən. jʌŋ kɛnli mɹɪn, hɪz tʃiks stɪl peɪl wɛɹ i hæd skɹeɪpt ɔf ɪz ətɛmpt əɾ ə bɪɹd, əvɔɪɾəd miɾɪŋ pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən dʒɔɹi kɔŋɡɝ, laɪtfɪŋɡɝd wɛnɛvɝ i sɔ ɛniθɪŋ smɔl ən væljəbəl ən dʒɹʌŋk wɛnɛvɝ i kəd mænədʒ ɪt, spæt kəntɛmptʃwəsli əz pɛɹɪn pæs baɪ. bæn kɹeɪ pʌntʃt dʒɔɹiz ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ ɪt, hɑɹd, bʌt bæn dɪd nɑt lʊk ət pɛɹɪn iðɝ.

Someone raised a halfhearted cry of "Goldeneyes!" but no one took it up, a thing that would have pleased Perrin a month gone. A great deal had changed since Faile was taken. Now their silence was leaden. Young Kenly Maerin, his cheeks still pale where he had scraped off his attempt at a beard, avoided meeting Perrin's eyes, and Jori Congar, lightfingered whenever he saw anything small and valuable and drunk whenever he could manage it, spat contemptuously as Perrin passed by. Ban Crawe punched Jori's shoulder for it, hard, but Ban did not look at Perrin either.

dænɪl luɪn stʊɾ ʌp, tʌɡɪŋ nɝvəsli ət ðə θɪk mʌstæʃ ðət lʊk soʊ ɹɪdɪkjələs bɪniθ ɪz bik ʌv ə noʊz.
