"ɔɹɾɝz, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?" ðə skɪni mæn æktʃəli  lʊkt ɹɪlivd wən pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən i sæt daʊn əɡɛn kwɪkli, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə nɪɹəs kɛɾəl əz ðoʊ hi wɝ æŋkʃəs fəɹ ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɡɹuɪl. meɪbi hi wɑz; noʊbɑdi ɡɑɾ ə fʊl bɛli leɪtli, ən dænɪl hæd nɛvɝ hæd mʌtʃ spɛɹ flɛʃ ɑn ɪz boʊnz. bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn, ɛɹæm meɪɾ ə dɪsɡʌstəd saʊn vɛɹi laɪk ə ɡɹaʊl.

Dannil Lewin stood up, tugging nervously at the thick mustache that looked so ridiculous beneath his beak of a nose. "Orders, Lord Perrin?" The skinny man actually looked relieved when Perrin shook his head, and he sat down again quickly, staring at the nearest kettle as though he were anxious for the morning gruel. Maybe he was; nobody got a full belly lately, and Dannil had never had much spare flesh on his bones. Behind Perrin, Aram made a disgusted sound very like a growl.

ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝz hɪɹ bɪsaɪdz tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ noʊ bɛɾɝ. oʊ, læmɡwɪn dɔɹn, ə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ wɪð skɑɹz ɑn ɪz feɪs, tʌɡd ɪz fɔɹlɑk ən bɑbd ɪz hɛd. læmɡwɪn lʊk laɪk ə ʃoʊldɝθʌmpɝ, ə tævɝn tʌf, bʌɾ i wɑz pɛɹɪnz bɑdaɪsɝvənt naʊ, wən i hæd niɾ ʌv wʌn, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ɔfən, ən i maɪt dʒʌst wɑnə kip ɪn ə ɡʊɾ oʊɾɝ wɪð ɪz ɛmplɔɪɝ. bʌt bɑzəl ɡɪl, ðə staʊt wʌntaɪm ɪnkipɝ feɪl hæd teɪkən ɑn əz ðɛɹ ʃæmbaɪən, bɪzid hɪmsɛlf foʊldɪŋ ɪz blæŋkəts wɪð ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd kɛɹ, kipɪŋ ɪz bɔldɪŋ hɛd daʊn, ən feɪlz tʃif meɪd, lini ɛltɝɪŋ, ə boʊni wʊmən huz taɪt waɪt bʌn meɪɾ əɹ feɪs sim ivən nɛɹoʊɝ ðən ɪt wɑz, stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm stɝɪŋ ə kɛɾəl, hɝ θɪn lɪps kəmpɹɛst, ən ɹeɪzd əɹ lɔŋ wʊɾən spun əz ɪf tə fɛn pɛɹɪn ɔf. bɹin tæbɔɹwɪn, dɑɹk aɪz fɪɹs ɪn əɹ peɪl kɛɹhinɪn feɪs, slæp læmɡwɪnz ɑɹm hɑɹɾ ən fɹaʊn ʌp ət hɪm. ʃi wɑz læmɡwɪnz wʊmən, ɪf nɑɾ ɪz waɪf, ən ðə sɛkən ə feɪlz θɹi meɪdz. ðeɪ wəd fɑloʊ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tɪl ðeɪ dʒɹɑp dɛd, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, ən fɔl ɑn feɪlz nɛk wən ðeɪ faʊn hɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli læmɡwɪn hæɾ ən aʊns ʌv wɛlkəm fəɹ pɛɹɪn. hi maɪɾ əv ɡɑɾən mɔɹ fɹəm dʒɝ ɡɹeɪɾi - ði æʃəmən wɝ ɛstʃɹeɪnʒd fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ðɛmsɛlvz, baɪ hu ən wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ən niðɝ hæd ʃoʊn ɛni ænəmɑsəɾi təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn - bʌt dɪspaɪt ðə nɔɪz ə pipəl tʃɹæmpɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɑn ðə fɹoʊzən snoʊ ən kɝsɪŋ wən ðeɪ slɪpt, ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz stɪl ɹæpt ɪn ɪz blæŋkəts, snɔɹɪŋ əweɪ bɪniθ ə paɪn-bɹæntʃ lin-tə. pɛɹɪn wɔk θɹu hɪz fɹɛnz ən neɪbɝz ən sɝvəns ən fɛlt əloʊn. ə mæn kəɾ oʊnli pɹoʊkleɪm ɪz feɪθfəlnəs soʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i dʒʌst ɡeɪv ʌp. ðə hɑɹɾ ə hɪz laɪf leɪ sʌmwɛɹ tə ðə nɔɹθist. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd ɹɪtɝn tə nɔɹməl wʌns i hæɾ əɹ bæk.

There were others here besides Two Rivers folk, yet they were no better. Oh, Lamgwin Dorn, a hulking fellow with scars on his face, tugged his forelock and bobbed his head. Lamgwin looked like a shoulderthumper, a tavern tough, but he was Perrin's bodyservant now, when he had need of one, which was not often, and he might just want to keep in a good odor with his employer. But Basel Gill, the stout onetime innkeeper Faile had taken on as their shambayan, busied himself folding his blankets with exaggerated care, keeping his balding head down, and Faile's chief maid, Lini Eltring, a bony woman whose tight white bun made her face seem even narrower than it was, straightened from stirring a kettle, her thin lips compressed, and raised her long wooden spoon as if to fend Perrin off. Breane Taborwin, dark eyes fierce in her pale Cairhienin face, slapped Lamgwin's arm hard and frowned up at him. She was Lamgwin's woman, if not his wife, and the second of Faile's three maids. They would follow the Shaido till they dropped dead, if necessary, and fall on Faile's neck when they found her, but only Lamgwin had an ounce of welcome for Perrin. He might have gotten more from Jur Grady - the Asha'man were estranged from everyone else themselves, by who and what they were, and neither had shown any animosity toward Perrin - but despite the noise of people tramping about on the frozen snow and cursing when they slipped, Grady was still wrapped in his blankets, snoring away beneath a pine-branch lean-to. Perrin walked through his friends and neighbors and servants and felt alone. A man could only proclaim his faithfulness so long before he just gave up. The heart of his life lay somewhere to the northeast. Everything would return to normal once he had her back.

ə θɪkɪɾ ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks tɛn peɪsɪz dip ɪnsɝkəl ðə kæmp, ən i wɛn tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡildænɪn lænsɝz' sɛkʃən, wɛɹ æŋɡəl pæðz hæd bɪn lɛft fəɹ maʊntəd mɛn tə ɹaɪɾ aʊt, ðoʊ beɪlwɝ ən ɛɹæm hæd tə fɔl ɪn bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪn ðə nɛɹoʊ weɪ. ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, ə mæn əfʊt wəɾ əv tə twɪst ən tɝn tə meɪk ɪt θɹu. ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɔɹəs leɪ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz dɪstənt, izi baʊʃɑt fəɹ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, hjudʒ tʃɹiz θɹʌstɪŋ ə kænəpi haɪ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. səm ə ðə tʃɹiz hɪɹ wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ tə pɛɹɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ paɪnz ən lɛðɝlif ən ɛlmz aʊt ðɛɹ, səm əz mʌtʃ əz θɹi əɹ fɔɹ peɪsɪz θɪk ət ðə beɪs, ən oʊks ðət wɝ lɑɹdʒɝ stɪl. tʃɹiz ðət bɪɡ kɪld ɛniθɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən widz əɹ smɔl bʊʃəz ðət tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɹoʊ bɪniθ ðɛm, livɪŋ waɪd speɪsəz bɪtwin, bʌt ʃædoʊz dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə naɪt fɪl ðoʊz speɪsəz. ən oʊl fɔɹəst, wʌn ðət kəd swɑloʊ ɑɹmiz hoʊl ən nɛvɝ ɡɪv ʌp ðə boʊnz. beɪlwɝ fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu ðə steɪks bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ðət ðɪs wɑz əz kloʊz tə əloʊn wɪð pɛɹɪn əz i wɑz laɪkli tə ɡɛɾ ɛni taɪm sun. "ðə ɹaɪɾɝz mæsimə hæz sɛn aʊt, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd, ən hoʊldɪŋ ɪz kloʊk kloʊs i kæst ə səspɪʃəs lʊk bæk əɾ ɛɹæm, hu mɛɾ ɪt wɪð ə flæt stɛɹ.

A thicket of sharpened stakes ten paces deep encircled the camp, and he went to the edge of the Ghealdanin lancers' section, where angled paths had been left for mounted men to ride out, though Balwer and Aram had to fall in behind him in the narrow way. In front of the Two Rivers men, a man afoot would have to twist and turn to make it through. The edge of the forest lay little more than a hundred paces distant, easy bowshot for Two Rivers men, huge trees thrusting a canopy high into the sky. Some of the trees here were strange to Perrin, but there were pines and leatherleaf and elms out there, some as much as three or four paces thick at the base, and oaks that were larger still. Trees that big killed anything larger than weeds or small bushes that tried to grow beneath them, leaving wide spaces between, but shadows darker than the night filled those spaces. An old forest, one that could swallow armies whole and never give up the bones. Balwer followed him all the way through the stakes before deciding that this was as close to alone with Perrin as he was likely to get any time soon. "The riders Masema has sent out, my Lord," he said, and holding his cloak close he cast a suspicious look back at Aram, who met it with a flat stare.

"aɪ noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ju θɪŋk ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə waɪtkloʊks." hi wɑz iɡɝ tə bi muvɪŋ, ən ðət mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ɪz fɹɛnz. hi pʊt ðə hæn hoʊldɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz ɑn ðə sæɾəlboʊ, bʌt ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm pʊɾɪŋ ə buɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp. stɛpɝ tɔst ɪz hɛd, ɔlsoʊ ɪmpeɪʃənt. "mæsimə kəd bi sɛndɪŋ mɛsədʒəz tə ðə sintʃæn dʒʌst əz izəli."

"I know," Perrin said, "you think they're going to the Whitecloaks." He was eager to be moving, and that much farther from his friends. He put the hand holding his reins on the saddlebow, but refrained from putting a boot in the stirrup. Stepper tossed his head, also impatient. "Masema could be sending messages to the Seanchan just as easily."

"æz juv sɛd, maɪ lɔɹd. ə vaɪəbəl pɑsəbɪləɾi, tə bi ʃʊɹ. meɪ aɪ sədʒɛst wʌns əɡɛn, haʊɛvɝ, ðət mæsiməz vju ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz vɛɹi kloʊz tə ðəɾ ə ðə waɪtkloʊks? ɪn fækt, aɪdɛntɪkəl. hi wəd si ɛvɹi læst sɪstɝ dɛd, ɪf i kʊd. ðə sintʃæn vju ɪz mɔɹ . . . pɹæɡmæɾɪk, ɪf aɪ meɪ bi pɝmɪɾəd tə kɔl ɪt ðæt. lɛs ɪn əkɔɹd wɪð mæsimə, ɪn ɛni keɪs."

"As you have said, my Lord. A viable possibility, to be sure. May I suggest once again, however, that Masema's view of Aes Sedai is very close to that of the Whitecloaks? In fact, identical. He would see every last sister dead, if he could. The Seanchan view is more . . . pragmatic, if I may be permitted to call it that. Less in accord with Masema, in any case."

"haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ jə heɪt waɪtkloʊks, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹən ət ðə ɹuɾ ʌv ɛvɹi ivəl. ən mæsimə hæz dɛlt wɪð ðə sintʃæn bɪfɔɹ."

"However much you hate Whitecloaks, Master Balwer, they aren't at the root of every evil. And Masema has dealt with the Seanchan before."

"æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd." beɪlwɝz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ i ɹikt ə daʊt. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt pɹuv mæsiməz miɾɪŋz wɪð ðə sintʃæn, ən tɛlɪŋ ɛniwʌn haʊ hi hæd lɝn ə ðɛm wəɾ oʊnli æd tə hɪz pɹɛzən dɪfəkəltiz. ðət ɡeɪv beɪlwɝ pɹɑbləmz; hi wɑz ə mæn u laɪkt ɛvəɾəns. "æz fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪz wʌnz, maɪ lɔɹd. . . . ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz sim tə bɪliv ðeɪ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls, ɪksɛpt pɑsəbli ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ bɪliv ðə waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm." pɛɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd bɹif waɪt plumz ɪn ði ɛɹ. "tɛl mi sʌmθɪŋ aɪ doʊnt noʊ. laɪk waɪ mɑsʊɝi wəd mit wɪð mæsimə, ən waɪ ðə waɪz wʌnz əlaʊɾ ɪt. əl weɪdʒɝ stɛpɝ əɡɛnst ə hɔɹsʃu neɪl ʃi dɪdn də ɪt wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ pɝmɪʃən." ənʊɹə wɑz ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən, bʌt ʃi kəd bi æktɪŋ ɑn əɹ oʊn. ɪt sɝɾənli simd ənlaɪkli ʃi wɑz æktɪŋ ət bɹəleɪnz bɪhɛst. ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, beɪlwɝ pɪɹd bæk əkɹɔs ðə ɹoʊz ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks ɪndə ðə kæmp, təwɔɹd ði il tɛns, skwɪntɪŋ əz ɪf i hoʊp tə si θɹu ðə tɛnt wɔlz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni pɑsəbɪləɾiz, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd tɛstəli. "fɔɹ səm u swɛɹ ən oʊθ, wʌtɛvɝ ɪz nɑt fɔɹbɪɾən ɪz pɝmɪɾəd, ən wʌtɛvɝ ɪz nɑt kəmændəd kən bi ɪɡnɔɹd. ʌðɝz teɪk ækʃənz ðeɪ bɪliv wɪl hɛlp ðɛɹ lidʒ wɪθaʊt fɝst æskɪŋ pɝmɪʃən. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪz wʌnz fɔl ɪndə wʌn ə ðoʊz kæɾəɡɔɹiz, ɪt simz, bʌt fɝðɝ ðən ðæt, aɪ kən oʊnli spɛkjəleɪt, əz mæɾɝz stænd." "aɪ kəd dʒʌst æsk. ɛɛs sədaɪ kæn laɪ, ən ɪf aɪ pɹɛs hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf, mɑsʊɝi maɪɾ æktʃəli  tɛl mi ðə tʃɹuθ."

"As you say, my Lord." Balwer's face did not change, but he reeked of doubt. Perrin could not prove Masema's meetings with the Seanchan, and telling anyone how he had learned of them would only add to his present difficulties. That gave Balwer problems; he was a man who liked evidence. "As for the Aes Sedai and the Wise Ones, my Lord. . . . Aes Sedai always seem to believe they know better than anyone else, except possibly another Aes Sedai. I believe the Wise Ones are much the same." Perrin snorted brief white plumes in the air. "Tell me something I don't know. Like why Masuri would meet with Masema, and why the Wise Ones allowed it. I'll wager Stepper against a horseshoe nail she didn't do it without their permission." Annoura was another question, but she could be acting on her own. It certainly seemed unlikely she was acting at Berelain's behest. Shifting his cloak on his shoulders, Balwer peered back across the rows of sharpened stakes into the camp, toward the Aiel tents, squinting as if he hoped to see through the tent walls. "There are many possibilities, my Lord," he said testily. "For some who swear an oath, whatever is not forbidden is permitted, and whatever is not commanded can be ignored. Others take actions they believe will help their liege without first asking permission. The Aes Sedai and the Wise Ones fall into one of those categories, it seems, but further than that, I can only speculate, as matters stand." "I could just ask. Aes Sedai can't lie, and if I press hard enough, Masuri might actually tell me the truth."

beɪlwɝ ɡɹɪməst əz ðoʊ əɾ ə sʌɾən stʌmək peɪn. "pɝhæps, maɪ lɔɹd. pɝhæps. mɔɹ laɪkli ɪz ðət ʃi wəd tɛl jə sʌmθɪŋ ðət saʊnz laɪk ðə tʃɹuθ. ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ ɪkspɪɹiənst ɪn ðæt, əz jə noʊ. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, maɪ lɔɹd, mɑsʊɝi wəd wʌndɝ haʊ jə nu tə æsk, ən ðət laɪn ə θɔt maɪt lɛd tə hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən. ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, hu kən seɪ hu ʃi maɪt tɛl?

Balwer grimaced as though at a sudden stomach pain. "Perhaps, my Lord. Perhaps. More likely is that she would tell you something that sounds like the truth. Aes Sedai are experienced in that, as you know. In any event, my Lord, Masuri would wonder how you knew to ask, and that line of thought might lead to Haviar and Nerion. Under the circumstances, who can say who she might tell?

stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə bɛst weɪ. səmtaɪmz, sɝɾən θɪŋz mʌs bi dʌn bɪhaɪn mæsks, fəɹ seɪfti." "aɪ toʊl jə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kʊdn bi tʃɹʌstɪd," ɛɹæm sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. "aɪ toʊl jə ðæt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn." hi fɛl saɪlənt wən pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ə hænd, bʌt ðə stɪŋk ə fjʊɹi fɹəm ɪm wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət pɛɹɪn hæd tə ɪksheɪl tə klɪɹ ɪz lʌŋz. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm wɑntəd tə dʒɹɔ ðə sɛn dip ən lɛɾ ɪt kənsum hɪm.

Straightforward is not always the best way. Sometimes, certain things must be done behind masks, for safety." "I told you the Aes Sedai couldn't be trusted," Aram said abruptly. "I told you that, Lord Perrin." He fell silent when Perrin raised a hand, but the stink of fury from him was so strong that Perrin had to exhale to clear his lungs. Part of him wanted to draw the scent deep and let it consume him.

pɛɹɪn stʌɾid beɪlwɝ kɛɹfəli. ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd twɪs ðə tʃɹuθ tɪl jə kəd nɑt tɛl ʌp fɹəm daʊn, ən ðeɪ kəɾ ən dɪd, haʊ fɑɹ kəd jə tʃɹʌst? tʃɹʌst wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə kwɛstʃən. hi hæd lɝn ðəɾ ɪn hɑɹd lɛsənz. hi tʊk ə fɝm tʃɛk ɑn ɪz æŋɡɝ, ðoʊ. ə hæmɝ hæd tə bi juzd wɪð kɛɹ, ən i wɑz wɝkɪŋ ə fɔɹdʒ wɛɹ wʌn slɪp wəd tɛɹ ðə hɑɹɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛst. "æn maɪt mæɾɝz tʃeɪnʒ ɪf səm ə sɛlənz fɹɛnz bɪɡæn spɛndɪŋ mɔɹ taɪm əmʌŋ ði il? ðeɪ wɑnə bi il, æftɝ ɔl.

Perrin studied Balwer carefully. If Aes Sedai could twist the truth till you could not tell up from down, and they could and did, how far could you trust? Trust was always the question. He had learned that in hard lessons. He took a firm check on his anger, though. A hammer had to be used with care, and he was working a forge where one slip would tear the heart out of his chest. "And might matters change if some of Selande's friends began spending more time among the Aiel? They want to be Aiel, after all.

ðəɾ ɔt tə ɡɪv əm ɪnʌf ɪkskjus. ən meɪbi wʌn ə ðɛm kən stʃɹaɪk ʌp ə fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð bɹəleɪn, ən wɪð əɹ ædvaɪzɝ." "ðæt ʃəd bi pɑsəbəl, maɪ lɔɹd," beɪlwɝ sɛɾ æftɝ ðə slaɪɾəst hɛzəteɪʃən. "leɪɾi mɛdɔɹz fɑðɝ ɪz ə haɪ lɔɹɾ ə tɛɹ, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ səfɪʃən ɹæŋk tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə fɝst ə min, ən ɔlsoʊ ə ɹizən. pɑsəbli wʌn əɹ tu ʌv ðə kɛɹhinɪn stæn haɪ ɪnʌf, əz wɛl. faɪndɪŋ ðoʊz tə lɪv əmʌŋ ði il wɪl bi iziɝ stɪl." pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ɪnfənət kɛɹ wɪð ðə hæmɝ, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ jə wɑntəd tə smæʃ wʌtɛvɝ leɪ wɪðɪn ɹitʃ. "ðɛn də ɪt. bʌt, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ, juv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə . . . ɡaɪd . . . mi tə ðɪs sɪns sɛlən lɛft ʌs. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, ɪf juv ə sədʒɛstʃən tə meɪk, meɪk ɪt. ivən ɪf aɪ seɪ noʊ tə naɪn ɪn ə ɹoʊ, əl ɔlweɪz lɪsən tə ə tɛnθ. aɪm nɑɾ ə klɛvɝ mæn, bʌɾ aɪm wɪlɪŋ tə lɪsən tə pipəl u ɑɹ, ən aɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ. dʒʌs doʊn tʃɹaɪ poʊkɪŋ mi ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən jə wɑn mi tə ɡoʊ. aɪ doʊn laɪk ðæt, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ." beɪlwɝ blɪŋkt, ðən ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, baʊd wɪð ɪz hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst. hi smɛl sɝpɹaɪzd. ən ɡɹæɾəfaɪd. ɡɹæɾəfaɪd? "æz jə seɪ, maɪ lɔɹd. maɪ pɹiviəs ɛmplɔɪɝ dɪslaɪk mi sədʒɛstɪŋ ækʃənz ənlɛs aɪ wɑz æskt. aɪ woʊn meɪk ðə seɪm mɪsteɪk əɡɛn, aɪ əʃʊɹ ju." aɪɪŋ pɛɹɪn, hi sim tə ɹitʃ ə dɪsɪʒən. "ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ," hi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "aɪ hæv faʊn sɝvɪŋ jə . . . plɛzənt . . . ɪn weɪz aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt. jə ɑɹ wʌt jə sim, maɪ lɔɹd, wɪð noʊ pɔɪzənd niɾəlz hɪɾən əweɪ tə kætʃ ði ənwɛɹi. maɪ pɹiviəs ɛmplɔɪɝ wɑz noʊn waɪdli fəɹ klɛvɝnəs, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv jə ɑɹ ikwəli klɛvɝ, ɪn ə dɪfɹənt weɪ. aɪ bɪliv aɪ wəd ɹəɡɹɛt livɪŋ jəɹ sɝvəs. ɛni mæn maɪt seɪ ðiz θɪŋz tə kip ɪz pleɪs, bʌɾ aɪ min ðɛm." pɔɪzənd niɾəlz? bɪfɔɹ ɛntɝɪŋ pɛɹɪnz sɝvəs, beɪlwɝz læst ɛmplɔɪmən hæd bɪn əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə ə mʊɹændiən noʊbəlwʊmən fɔlən ɪndə hɑɹd taɪmz u kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɔɹd tə kip hɪm.

That ought to give them enough excuse. And maybe one of them can strike up a friendship with Berelain, and with her advisor." "That should be possible, my Lord," Balwer said after the slightest hesitation. "Lady Medore's father is a High Lord of Tear, giving her sufficient rank to approach the First of Mayene, and also a reason. Possibly one or two of the Cairhienin stand high enough, as well. Finding those to live among the Aiel will be easier still." Perrin nodded. Infinite care with the hammer, however much you wanted to smash whatever lay within reach. "Then do it. But, Master Balwer, you've been trying to . . . guide . . . me to this since Selande left us. From now on, if you have a suggestion to make, make it. Even if I say no to nine in a row, I'll always listen to a tenth. I'm not a clever man, but I'm willing to listen to people who are, and I think you are. Just don't try poking me in the direction you want me to go. I don't like that, Master Balwer." Balwer blinked, then of all things, bowed with his hands folded at his waist. He smelled surprised. And gratified. Gratified? "As you say, my Lord. My previous employer disliked me suggesting actions unless I was asked. I won't make the same mistake again, I assure you." Eyeing Perrin, he seemed to reach a decision. "If I may say so," he said carefully, "I have found serving you . . . pleasant . . . in ways I did not expect. You are what you seem, my Lord, with no poisoned needles hidden away to catch the unwary. My previous employer was known widely for cleverness, but I believe you are equally clever, in a different way. I believe I would regret leaving your service. Any man might say these things to keep his place, but I mean them." Poisoned needles? Before entering Perrin's service, Balwer's last employment had been as secretary to a Murandian noblewoman fallen into hard times who could no longer afford to keep him.

mʊɹændi mʌs bi ə ɹʌfɝ pleɪs ðən pɛɹɪn θɔt. "aɪ si noʊ ɹizən fəɹ jə tə liv maɪ ɛmplɔɪ. dʒʌs tɛl mi wʌt jə wɑnə də ən lemi dɪsaɪd, doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə pɹɑd. ən fɝɡɛt ðə flæɾɝi."

Murandy must be a rougher place than Perrin thought. "I see no reason for you to leave my employ. Just tell me what you want to do and let me decide, don't try to prod. And forget the flattery."

"aɪ nɛvɝ flæɾɝ, maɪ lɔɹd. bʌɾ aɪm ədɛpt ət ʃeɪpɪŋ maɪsɛlf tə maɪ mæstɝz nidz; ɪts ə ɹɪkwaɪɹmən ə maɪ pɹəfɛʃən." ðə lɪɾəl mæn baʊd wʌns mɔɹ. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðɪs fɔɹməl bɪfɔɹ.

"I never flatter, my Lord. But I am adept at shaping myself to my master's needs; it is a requirement of my profession." The little man bowed once more. He had never been this formal before.

"ɪf juv noʊ fɝðɝ kwɛstʃənz, maɪ lɔɹd, meɪ aɪ ɡoʊ tə faɪn ðə leɪɾi mɛdɔɹ?" pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. ðə lɪɾəl mæn baʊd jɛɾ əɡɛn, bækɪŋ əweɪ, ðən wɛn skɪɾɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, hɪz kloʊk flʌɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪm əz i dɑdʒ θɹu ðə ʃɑɹpən steɪks laɪk ə spɛɹoʊ hɑpɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ. hi wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fɛloʊ.

"If you have no further questions, my Lord, may I go to find the Lady Medore?" Perrin nodded. The little man bowed yet again, backing away, then went skittering toward the camp, his cloak fluttering behind him as he dodged through the sharpened stakes like a sparrow hopping across the snow. He was a strange fellow.

"aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌs hɪm," ɛɹæm mʌɾɝd, stɛɹɪŋ æftɝ beɪlwɝ. "æn aɪ doʊn tʃɹʌst sɛlən ən ðət lɑt.

"I don't trust him," Aram muttered, staring after Balwer. "And I don't trust Selande and that lot.

ðəl θɹoʊ ɪn wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, jə mɑɹk maɪ wɝdz."

They'll throw in with the Aes Sedai, you mark my words."

"ju hæv tə tʃɹʌst sʌmbɑɾi," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɹʌfli. ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz, hu? swɪŋɪŋ ɪndə stɛpɝz sæɾəl, hi buɾɪd ðə dʌn ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. ə hæmɝ wɑz jusləs laɪɪŋ ət ɹɛst.

"You have to trust somebody," Perrin said roughly. The question was, who? Swinging into Stepper's saddle, he booted the dun in the ribs. A hammer was useless lying at rest.

tʃæptɝ sɪks

CHAPTER 6

ðə sɛn ʌv ə dʒɹim ðə koʊld ɛɹ sim klin ən fɹɛʃ ɪn pɛɹɪnz noʊz əz i ɡæləpt ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, ðə bɹizɪz fʊl ə ðə kɹɪspnəs ə ðə snoʊ ðət faʊnteɪn ɪn spɹeɪz bɪniθ stɛpɝz hʊvz. aʊt hɪɹ, hi kəd fɝɡɛɾ oʊl fɹɛnz u wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə bɪliv ðə wɝst ɑn ɹumɝ. hi kəd tʃɹaɪ tə fɝɡɛt mæsimə, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə waɪz wʌnz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ wɛldɪd tə ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz skʌl, haʊɛvɝ, ən aɪɝn pʌzəl ðət wəd nɑt jil noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hi twɪstəd. hi wɑntəd tə ɹɛntʃ ɪɾ əpɑɹt, bʌt ðət nɛvɝ wɝkt wɪð ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl.

The Scent of a Dream The cold air seemed clean and fresh in Perrin's nose as he galloped into the forest, the breezes full of the crispness of the snow that fountained in sprays beneath Stepper's hooves. Out here, he could forget old friends who were willing to believe the worst on rumor. He could try to forget Masema, and the Aes Sedai, and the Wise Ones. The Shaido were welded to the inside of his skull, however, an iron puzzle that would not yield no matter how he twisted. He wanted to wrench it apart, but that never worked with a blacksmith's puzzle.

æftɝ wʌn ʃɔɹt bɝst ə spid, hi sloʊd ðə dʌn tə ə wɔk, filɪŋ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɪlt. ðə dɑɹknəs bɪniθ ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi wɑz dip, ən stoʊn aʊtkɹɑps bɪtwin ðə tɔl tʃɹiz wɔɹn ə mɔɹ hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə snoʊ, ə hʌnʒɹəd pleɪsəz ðət kəd bɹeɪk ə ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹsəz lɛɡ, ən ðət wɪθaʊt kaʊntɪŋ ɡoʊfɝ hoʊlz ən fɑks dɛnz ən bædʒɝ sɛts. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə teɪk ðə ɹɪsk. ə ɡæləp wəd nɑt fɹi feɪl ən aʊɝ sunɝ, ən noʊ hɔɹs kəd meɪnteɪn ðət peɪs fəɹ lɔŋ ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðə snoʊ hɪɹ wɑz ni-dip ɪn pleɪsəz wɛɹ ɪt hæd dʒɹɪftəd, ən dip ɪnʌf ɛlswɛɹ. hi ɹoʊd nɔɹθist, ðoʊ. ðə skaʊts wəd bi kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθist, wɪð nuz ə feɪl. nuz ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ət list, ə loʊkeɪʃən.

After one short burst of speed, he slowed the dun to a walk, feeling a touch of guilt. The darkness beneath the forest canopy was deep, and stone outcrops between the tall trees warned of more hidden beneath the snow, a hundred places that could break a running horse's leg, and that without counting gopher holes and fox dens and badger sets. There was no need to take the risk. A gallop would not free Faile an hour sooner, and no horse could maintain that pace for long in any case. The snow here was knee-deep in places where it had drifted, and deep enough elsewhere. He rode northeast, though. The scouts would be coming from the northeast, with news of Faile. News of the Shaido, at least, a location.

hi hæd hoʊp fəɹ ðət soʊ ɔfən, pɹeɪd fəɹ ɪt, bʌt tədeɪ, hi nu ɪt wəd kʌm. jɛt noʊɪŋ oʊnli ɪnkɹist ɪz æŋzaɪəɾi. faɪndɪŋ əm wɑz oʊnli ðə fɝs pɑɹɾ ə sɑlvɪŋ ðɪs pʌzəl. æŋɡɝ meɪɾ ɪz maɪn flæʃ fɹəm wʌn θɪŋ tə ənʌðɝ, jɛt noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt beɪlwɝ sɛd, pɛɹɪn nu hi wɑz məθɑɾəkəl ət bɛst.

He had hoped for that so often, prayed for it, but today, he knew it would come. Yet knowing only increased his anxiety. Finding them was only the first part of solving this puzzle. Anger made his mind flash from one thing to another, yet no matter what Balwer said, Perrin knew he was methodical at best.

hi dɪd nɑt də wɛl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk kwɪkli, ən lækɪŋ klɛvɝnəs, məθɑɾəkəl wɑz gɑnə hæv tə du.

He did not do well trying to think quickly, and lacking cleverness, methodical was going to have to do.

sʌmhaʊ.

Somehow.

ɛɹæm kɑɾ ʌp tə hɪm, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz ɡɹeɪ hɑɹd, ən sloʊd tə ɹaɪd dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn ən tə wʌn saɪd laɪk ə hilɪŋ haʊnd. pɛɹɪn lɛt hɪm. ɛɹæm nɛvɝ smɛl kʌmftəɹbəl wən pɛɹɪn meɪɾ ɪm ɹaɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd. ðə wʌntaɪm tɪŋkɝ dɪd nɑt spik, bʌɾ ɛɾiz ɪn ði aɪsi ɛɹ bɹɔɾ ɪz sɛnt, ə mɛlæŋ ʌv æŋɡɝ ən səspɪʃən ən dɪsɡɹʌntəlmənt. hi sæɾ ɪz sæɾəl əz tɛns əz ən oʊvɝ-waʊn klɑkspɹɪŋ ən wɑtʃt ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn əm ɡɹɪmli, əz ðoʊ hi ɪkspɛktəd ʃeɪɾoʊ tə lip aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə nɪɹəs tʃɹi. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ cʊɾə hɪɾən fɹəm moʊs mɛn ɪn ðiz wʊdz. wɛɹ ðə skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd kəd bi sin θɹu ðə kænəpi ʌv bɹæntʃəz, ɪt hɛld ə dɛfənət tɪnʒ ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪnəs, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊmən ðət kæs ðə fɔɹəst ɪn ʃædoʊz mɝkiɝ ðən naɪt, ən ðə tʃɹiz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ mæsɪv kɑləmz ə dɑɹknəs. jɛɾ ivən ðə ʃɪft ʌv ə blæk-wɪŋ dʒækdɔ ɑn ə snoʊ-maʊndɪd bɹæntʃ, ɪts fɛðɝz flʌft əɡɛns ðə koʊld, kɑt pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən ə hʌntɪŋ paɪn mɑɹɾən, ə dipɝ blæk ðən ðə dɑɹknəs, kɔʃəsli ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪts hɛɾ ɑn ənʌðɝ. hi kɑt ðə sɛn ə boʊθ, tu. ə feɪnt wɪf ə mæn sɛn keɪm fɹəm ʌp ɪn ə mæsɪv oʊk wɪð dɑɹk spɹɛɾɪŋ lɪmz əz θɪk əz ə poʊni. ðə ɡildænɪn ən minɝz hæd ðɛɹ maʊntəd pətʃɹoʊlz sɝkəlɪŋ ðə kæmp ə fju maɪlz aʊt, bʌɾ i pɹəfɝd tə ɹɪlaɪ ɑn tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn kloʊsɝ ɪn. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv ɪnʌf mɛn tə ɹɪŋ ðə kæmp kəmplitli, jɛt ðeɪ wɝ juz tə fɔɹəsts, ən tə hʌntɪŋ ænəməlz ðət maɪt hʌn əm ɪn tɝn, juz tə noʊɾɪsɪŋ muvmən ðət wəɾ ɪskeɪp ə mæn θɪŋkɪŋ ɪn tɝmz ə soʊlʒɝz ən wɔɹ. ɹɪdʒɛkæts daʊn fɹəm ðə maʊntənz æftɝ ʃip kəd haɪɾ ɪn pleɪn saɪt, ən bɛɹ ən waɪl bɔɹ wɝ noʊn tə dʌbəl bæk ɑn ðɛɹ pɝsuɝz ən laɪ ɪn æmbʊʃ.

Aram caught up to him, running his gray hard, and slowed to ride just a little behind and to one side like a heeling hound. Perrin let him. Aram never smelled comfortable when Perrin made him ride alongside. The onetime Tinker did not speak, but eddies in the icy air brought his scent, a melange of anger and suspicion and disgruntlement. He sat his saddle as tense as an over-wound clockspring and watched the forest around them grimly, as though he expected Shaido to leap out from behind the nearest tree. In truth, almost anything could have hidden from most men in these woods. Where the sky overhead could be seen through the canopy of branches, it held a definite tinge of dark grayness, but for the moment that cast the forest in shadows murkier than night, and the trees themselves were massive columns of darkness. Yet even the shift of a black-winged jackdaw on a snow-mounded branch, its feathers fluffed against the cold, caught Perrin's eyes, and a hunting pine martin, a deeper black than the darkness, cautiously raising its head on another. He caught the scent of both, too. A faint whiff of man scent came from up in a massive oak with dark spreading limbs as thick as a pony. The Ghealdanin and Mayeners had their mounted patrols circling the camp a few miles out, but he preferred to rely on Two Rivers men closer in. He did not have enough men to ring the camp completely, yet they were used to forests, and to hunting animals that might hunt them in turn, used to noticing movement that would escape a man thinking in terms of soldiers and war. Ridgecats down from the mountains after sheep could hide in plain sight, and bear and wild boar were known to double back on their pursuers and lie in ambush.

fɹəm bɹæntʃəz θɝɾi ən fɔɹɾi fiɾ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðə mɛn kəd si ɛniθɪŋ ðət muv bɪloʊ ɪn taɪm tə wɔɹn ðə kæmp, ən wɪð ðɛɹ lɔŋboʊz, ðeɪ kəɾ ɪɡzækt ə hɛvi pɹaɪs fɹəm ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹs ə weɪ pæs ðɛm. jɛt ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə ɡɑɹd tʌtʃt ɪz maɪn əz laɪtli əz ðə tɛzəns ə ðə dʒækdɔ. hi wɑz foʊkəst əhɛd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ən ðə ʃædoʊz, ɪntɛn ɑn pɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə fɝst saɪn ə ðə skaʊts ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. əbɹʌpli stɛpɝ tɔst ɪz hɛɾ ən snɔɹɾɪd ɪn ə spju ʌv mɪst, aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn fɪɹ əz i stɑp dɛd, ən ɛɹæmz ɡɹeɪ skwild ən ʃaɪd. pɛɹɪn lin fɔɹwɝd tə pæt ðə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ stæljənz nɛk, bʌɾ ɪz hæn fɹoʊz əz i kɑɾ ə tʃɹeɪs ə sɛnt, ə smɛl ə bɝn sʌlfɝ feɪn ɪn ði ɛɹ, ðət meɪd ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk tʃɹaɪ tə stænd. ɔlmoʊs bɝn sʌlfɝ; ðət wɑz oʊnli ə peɪl ɪməteɪʃən ə ðɪs smɛl. ɪt hæɾ ə ɹik ʌv. . . ɹɔŋɡnəs, ʌv sʌmθɪŋ ðət dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ ɪn ðɪs wɝld. ðə sɛnt wɑz nɑt nu - jə kəd nɑɾ ɛvɝ əv kɔl ðət stɪŋk "fɹɛʃ" - bʌt nɑɾ oʊld, iðɝ. ən aʊɝ, pɝhæps lɛs. meɪbi əbaʊt ðə taɪm i hæd wækənd. əbaʊt ðə taɪm i hæd dʒɹimd ə ðɪs sɛnt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?" ɛɹæm wɑz hævɪŋ dɪfəkəlti kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz ɡɹeɪ, wɪtʃ dænst ɪn sɝkəlz faɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ən wɑntɪŋ tə ɹʌn ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz əweɪ, bʌɾ ivən waɪl sɔɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz i hæɾ ɪz wʊlfhɛd-pɑməl sɔɹɾ aʊt. hi pɹæktəst wɪð ɪt deɪli, fəɹ aʊɝz ɑn ɛnd wən i kʊd, ən ðoʊz u nu əbaʊt sətʃ θɪŋz sɛɾ i wɑz ɡʊd. "ju meɪ bi eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊɾ ə blæk θɹɛd fɹəm ə waɪɾ ɪn ðɪs, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪzən deɪ jɛt tə mi. aɪ kæn si ɛniθɪŋ wɛl ɪnʌf tə mæɾɝ." "pʊt ðəɾ əweɪ," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "ɪɾ ɪzənt niɾəd. sɔɹdz wʊdn də ɛni ɡʊd, ɛniweɪ." hi hæd tə koʊks ɪz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ maʊn tə muv fɔɹwɝd, bʌɾ i fɑloʊd ðə ɹæŋk smɛl, skænɪŋ ðə snoʊ-kʌvɝd ɡɹaʊn əhɛd. hi nu ðət smɛl, ən nɑt dʒʌs fɹəm ðə dʒɹim.

From branches thirty and forty feet above the ground, the men could see anything that moved below in time to warn the camp, and with their longbows, they could exact a heavy price from anyone who tried to force a way past them. Yet the presence of the guard touched his mind as lightly as the ptesence of the jackdaw. He was focused ahead through the trees and the shadows, intent on picking out the first sign of the scouts returning. Abruptly Stepper tossed his head and snorted in a spew of mist, eyes rolling in fear as he stopped dead, and Aram's gray squealed and shied. Perrin leaned forward to pat the trembling stallion's neck, but his hand froze as he caught a trace of scent, a smell of burned sulphur faint in the air, that made the hair on the back of his neck try to stand. Almost burnt sulphur; that was only a pale imitation of this smell. It had a reek of. . . wrongness, of something that did not belong in this world. The scent was not new - you could not ever have called that stink "fresh" - but not old, either. An hour, perhaps less. Maybe about the time he had wakened. About the time he had dreamed of this scent. "What is it, Lord Perrin?" Aram was having difficulty controlling his gray, which danced in circles fighting the reins and wanting to run in any direction so long as it was away, but even while sawing at his reins he had his wolfhead-pommeled sword out. He practiced with it daily, for hours on end when he could, and those who knew about such things said he was good. "You may be able to make out a black thread from a white in this, but it isn't day yet to me. I can't see anything well enough to matter." "Put that away," Perrin told him. "It isn't needed. Swords wouldn't do any good, anyway." He had to coax his trembling mount to move forward, but he followed the rank smell, scanning the snow-covered ground ahead. He knew that smell, and not just from the dream.

ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk ə lɪɾəl waɪl tə faɪnd wʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ, ən stɛpɝ ɡeɪv ə ɡɹeɪtfəl wɪkɝ wən pɛɹɪn ɹeɪn ɪm ɪn wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə slæb-laɪk kɹɛst ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, tu peɪsɪz waɪd, ðət dʒʌɾɪd ʌp tə hɪz ɹaɪt. ðə snoʊ ɔl ɝaʊnd wɑz smuð ən ənmɑɹkt, bʌt dɔɡ tʃɹæks kʌvɝd ðə tɪltəd spæn ə stoʊn, əz ðoʊ ə pæk hæd skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ ɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹæn. dɪmnəs ən ʃædoʊz əɹ noʊ, ðeɪ wɝ pleɪn tə pɛɹɪnz aɪz. fʊtpɹɪns lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðə pɑm ə hɪz hænd, pɹɛst ɪndə ðə stoʊn əz ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn mʌd. hi pæɾəd stɛpɝz nɛk əɡɛn. noʊ wʌndɝ ði ænəməl wɑz fɹaɪɾənd.

It only took a little while to find what he was looking for, and Stepper gave a grateful whicker when Perrin reined him in well short of a slab-like crest of gray stone, two paces wide, that jutted up to his right. The snow all around was smooth and unmarked, but dog tracks covered the tilted span of stone, as though a pack had scrambled over it as they ran. Dimness and shadows or no, they were plain to Perrin's eyes. Footprints larger than the palm of his hand, pressed into the stone as though it had been mud. He patted Stepper's neck again. No wonder the animal was frightened.

"ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə kæmp ən faɪn dænɪl, ɛɹæm. tɛl ɪm aɪ sɛd tə lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn noʊ ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹkhaʊnz hɪɹ, meɪbi ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ. ən pʊt jəɹ sɔɹɾ əweɪ. jə wʊdnt wɑnə tʃɹaɪ kɪlɪŋ ə dɑɹkhaʊnd wɪð ə sɔɹd, bɪliv mi."

"Go back to the camp and find Dannil, Aram. Tell him I said to let everyone know there were Darkhounds here, maybe an hour ago. And put your sword away. You wouldn't want to try killing a Darkhound with a sword, believe me."

"dɑɹkhaʊnz?" ɛɹæm ɪkskleɪmd, piɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪndə ðə mɝki ʃædoʊz bɪtwin ðə tʃɹiz.

"Darkhounds?" Aram exclaimed, peering around into the murky shadows between the trees.

ðəɹ wɑz ən æŋkʃəs fɪɹ ɪn ɪz sɛnt, naʊ. moʊs mɛn wʊɾə læft əbaʊt tʃɹævəlɝz' teɪlz əɹ stɔɹiz fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. tɪŋkɝz ɹoʊm ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, ən nu wʌt kəd faʊn ɪn ðə waɪlz. ɛɹæm ʃiðd ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð ɑbviəs ɹɪlʌktəns, bʌɾ ɪz ɹaɪt hæn ɹɪmeɪn ɹeɪzd, hæf-ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə hɪlt. "haʊ dʒju kɪl ə dɑɹkhaʊnd? kən ðeɪ bi kɪld?" ðən əɡɛn, meɪbi hi dɪd nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ ɡʊd sɛns ət ðæt.

There was an anxious fear in his scent, now. Most men would have laughed about travelers' tales or stories for children. Tinkers roamed the countryside, and knew what could found in the wilds. Aram sheathed the sword on his back with obvious reluctance, but his right hand remained raised, half-reaching for the hilt. "How do you kill a Darkhound? Can they be killed?" Then again, maybe he did not have much good sense at that.

"dʒʌs bi ɡlæd jə doʊn əv tə tʃɹaɪ, ɛɹæm. naʊ ɡoʊ də laɪk aɪ toʊl ju. ɛvɹiwʌn nidz tə kip ə ʃɑɹp lʊkaʊɾ ɪn keɪs ðeɪ kʌm bæk. nɑt mʌtʃ tʃæns ə ðæt, aɪd seɪ, bʌt bɛɾɝ seɪf." pɛɹɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd feɪsɪŋ ə pæk ə ðɛm wʌns, ən kɪlɪŋ wʌn. hi θɔɾ i hæd kɪld wʌn, æftɝ hɪɾɪŋ ɪt wɪð θɹi ɡʊd bɹɔdhɛɾ æɹoʊz. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn dɪd nɑt daɪ izəli. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd hæd tə fɪnɪʃ ðət pæk, wɪð bɑlfaɪɝ. "meɪk ʃʊɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz lɝn ə ðɪs, ən ði æʃəmən." smɔl tʃæns ɛni ʌv əm nu haʊ tə meɪk bɑlfaɪɝ - ðə wɪmən maɪt nɑɾ ədmɪt noʊɪŋ ə fɔɹbɪɾən wiv ɪf ðeɪ dɪd, ən meɪbi nɑt ðə mɛn iðɝ - bʌt meɪbi ðeɪ nu sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðət kəd wɝk.

"Just be glad you don't have to try, Aram. Now go do like I told you. Everyone needs to keep a sharp lookout in case they come back. Not much chance of that, I'd say, but better safe." Perrin remembered facing a pack of them once, and killing one. He thought he had killed one, after hitting it with three good broadhead arrows. Shadowspawn did not die easily. Moiraine had had to finish that pack, with balefire. "Make sure the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones learn of this, and the Asha'man." Small chance any of them knew how to make balefire - the women might not admit knowing a forbidden weave if they did, and maybe not the men either - but maybe they knew something else that could work.

ɛɹæm wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə liv pɛɹɪn əloʊn əntɪl pɛɹɪn snæpt ət hɪm, ən ðən i tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp tʃɹeɪlɪŋ smɛlz ʌv ʌmbɹɪdʒ ən hɝt, əz ɪf tu mɛn wʊɾə bɪn ə wɪt seɪfɝ ðən wʌn. əz sun əz ði ʌðɝ mæn wɑz aʊɾ ə saɪt, pɛɹɪn ɹeɪn stɛpɝ saʊθwɝd, ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz hæd bɪn hɛɾɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn kʌmpəni fəɹ ðɪs, ivən ɛɹæmz. dʒʌs kəz pipəl səmtaɪmz noʊɾəd ɪz ʃɑɹp aɪsaɪt wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə flɔn ɪt, əɹ ɪz sɛns ə smɛl. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹizənz ɪnʌf tə ʃʌn ɪm wɪθaʊɾ æɾɪŋ mɔɹ.

Aram was reluctant to leave Perrin alone until Perrin snapped at him, and then he turned back toward the camp trailing smells of umbrage and hurt, as if two men would have been a whit safer than one. As soon as the other man was out of sight, Perrin reined Stepper southward, the direction the Darkhounds had been heading. He did not want company for this, even Aram's. Just because people sometimes noted his sharp eyesight was no reason to flaunt it, or his sense of smell. There were already reasons enough to shun him without adding more.

ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn tʃæns ðət ðə kɹitʃɝz hæd pæst soʊ nɪɹ ɪz kæmp, bʌt ðə læs fju jɪɹz hæd meɪɾ ɪm ənizi wɪð koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz. ɔl tu ɔfən, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt koʊɪnsɪɾəns əɾ ɔl, nɑt ðə weɪ ʌðɝ mɛn kaʊntəd sətʃ θɪŋz. ɪf ðɪs wɑz ənʌðɝ bɪɾ ə hɪz tɑ'-vɹən tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə pæɾɝn, ɪt wɑz ə bɪɾ i cʊɾə dʌn wɪθaʊt.

It might have been chance that the creatures had passed so near his camp, but the last few years had made him uneasy with coincidences. All too often, they were not coincidence at all, not the way other men counted such things. If this was another bit of his ta'-veren tugging at the Pattern, it was a bit he could have done without.

ðə θɪŋ sim tə hæv mɔɹ dɪsədvæntɪdʒɪz ðən ædvæntɪdʒɪz ivən wən ɪɾ əpɪɹd tə bi wɝkɪŋ ɪn jəɹ feɪvɝ. ðə tʃæns ðət feɪvɝd jə wʌn mɪnət kəd tɝn ɑn jə ɪn ðə nɛkst. ən ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ənʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾi. biɪŋ tɑvɝən meɪd jə stæn aʊɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, ən səm ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən kəd juz ðət tə faɪn jə ət taɪmz, əɹ soʊ hi hæd bɪn toʊld. meɪbi səm ʃæɾoʊzpɔn kʊd, tu.

The thing seemed to have more disadvantages than advantages even when it appeared to be working in your favor. The chance that favored you one minute could turn on you in the next. And there was always another possibility. Being ta'veren made you stand out in the Pattern, and some of the Forsaken could use that to find you at times, or so he had been told. Maybe some Shadowspawn could, too.

ðə tʃɹeɪl i fɑloʊd wɑz ʃʊɹli nɪɹ ən aʊɝ oʊld, bʌt pɛɹɪn fɛlt ə taɪtnəs bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz, ə pɹɪklɪŋ ɑn ɪz skælp. ðə skaɪ wɑz stɪl ə dip dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wɛɹ ɪt ʃoʊd, ivən tə hɪz aɪz.

The trail he followed was surely near an hour old, but Perrin felt a tightness between his shoulder blades, a prickling on his scalp. The sky was still a deep dark gray where it showed, even to his eyes.

ðə sʌn hæd nɑt jɛt kɹɛstəd ðə hɝaɪzən. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ sʌnɹaɪz wɑz wʌn ə ðə wɝs taɪmz tə mit ðə waɪl hʌnt, wən dɑɹknəs wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ tə laɪt bʌt ðə laɪt hæd nɑt teɪkən hoʊld. ət lis ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɹɔsɹoʊdz nɪɹbaɪ, noʊ ɡɹeɪvjɑɹd, bʌt ði oʊnli hɑɹθstoʊnz tə tʌtʃ leɪ bæk ɪn bɹaɪɾən, ən i wɑz nɑt sɝɾən haʊ mʌtʃ seɪfti ðoʊz hʌvəlz hɛld. ɪn ɪz maɪnd, hi mɑɹkt aʊt ðə loʊkeɪʃən ʌv ə nɪɹbaɪ stʃɹim, wɛɹ ðə kæmp ɡɑɾ ɪts wɔɾɝ baɪ tʃɑpɪŋ θɹu ði aɪs. ɪt wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən tɛn əɹ twɛlv peɪsɪz waɪɾ ən oʊnli ni-dip, bʌt pʊɾɪŋ ɹʌnɪŋ wɔɾɝ bɪtwin jə ən dɑɹkhaʊnz wəd stɑp əm səpoʊzədli. bʌt ðɛn, soʊ wəd feɪsɪŋ ðɛm, səpoʊzədli, ən i hæd sin ðə ɹɪzʌls ə ðæt. hɪz noʊz tɛstəd ðə bɹizɪz, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðəɾ oʊl sɛnt. ən fəɹ ɛni hɪn ʌv ə nuɝ. kʌmɪŋ ɑn ðoʊz θɪŋz ʌnəwɛɹ wəd bi wɝs ðən ənplɛzənt.

The sun had not yet crested the horizon. Just before sunrise was one of the worst times to meet the Wild Hunt, when darkness was changing to light but the light had not taken hold. At least there was no crossroads nearby, no graveyard, but the only hearthstones to touch lay back in Brytan, and he was not certain how much safety those hovels held. In his mind, he marked out the location of a nearby stream, where the camp got its water by chopping through the ice. It was no more than ten or twelve paces wide and only knee-deep, but putting running water between you and Darkhounds would stop them supposedly. But then, so would facing them, supposedly, and he had seen the results of that. His nose tested the breezes, searching for that old scent. And for any hint of a newer. Coming on those things unaware would be worse than unpleasant.

stɛpɝ kɑt sɛns ɔlmoʊst əz izəli əz pɛɹɪn, ən səmtaɪmz noʊɾəst wʌt ðeɪ wɝ sunɝ, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ðə dʌn bɔkt, pɛɹɪn fɔɹst ɪm fɔɹwɝd. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv tʃɹæks skæɾɝd ɪn ðə snoʊ, hʊfpɹɪns ə ðə maʊntəd pətʃɹoʊlz ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ən kʌmɪŋ bæk, əkeɪʒənəl saɪn ə ɹæbəts ən fɑksəz, bʌt ði oʊnli mɑɹks lɛf baɪ ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz wɝ wɛɹ stoʊn stʌk ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ. ðə bɝn sʌlfɝ smɛl wɑz ɔlweɪz stʃɹɔŋɡəs ðɛɹ, jɛɾ ɪnʌf tʃɹeɪs lɪŋɡɝɾ ɪn bɪtwin tə liɾ ɪm tə ðə nɛks pleɪs wɛɹ ðɛɹ tʃɹæks ʃoʊd. ðə hjudʒ pɔpɹɪns oʊvɝlæpt wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl haʊ mɛni dɑɹkhaʊnz ðəɹ hæd bɪn, bʌt wɛðɝ ə peɪs waɪɾ əɹ sɪks, ɛvɹi ɹɑk sɝfəs ðeɪ hæd kɹɔst wɑz smʌðɝɾ ɪn tʃɹæks fɹəm wʌn saɪd tə ði ʌðɝ. ə lɑɹdʒɝ pæk ðən ðə tɛn i hæd sin aʊtsaɪɾ ɪljən. mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ. wɑz ðət waɪ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wʊlvz ɪn ði ɛɹiə? hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət ðə sɝɾənti ʌv dɛθ i hæd fɛlt ɪn ðə dʒɹim wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹil, ən i hæd bɪn ə wʊlf ɪn ðə dʒɹim.

Stepper caught scents almost as easily as Perrin, and sometimes noticed what they were sooner, but whenever the dun balked, Perrin forced him forward. There were plenty of tracks scattered in the snow, hoofprints of the mounted patrols going out and coming back, occasional sign of rabbits and foxes, but the only marks left by the Darkhounds were where stone stuck up out of the snow. The burnt sulphur smell was always strongest there, yet enough trace lingered in between to lead him to the next place where their tracks showed. The huge pawprints overlapped one another, and there was no way to tell how many Darkhounds there had been, but whether a pace wide or six, every rock surface they had crossed was smothered in tracks from one side to the other. A larger pack than the ten he had seen outside Illian. Much larger. Was that why there were no wolves in the area? He was sure that the certainty of death he had felt in the dream was something real, and he had been a wolf in the dream.

əz ðə tʃɹeɪl bɪɡæn tə kɝv tə ðə wɛst, hi fɛlt ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ səspɪʃən ðət fɝmd ɪndə sɝɾənti əz ɪt kəntɪnjud tə bɛnd. ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz hæd sɝkəl ðə kæmp kəmplitli, ɹʌnɪŋ ɹaɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə pleɪs nɔɹθ ə ðə kæmp wɛɹ sɛvɹəl hjudʒ tʃɹiz leɪ hæf tɑpəld ən pɹɑp baɪ ðɛɹ neɪbɝz, itʃ wɪð ə tɔl tʃʌŋk slaɪs klinli aʊɾ ʌv ɪts splɪntɝd tʃɹʌŋk. ðə tʃɹæks kʌvɝɾ ə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp əz smuð ən flæɾ əz ə pɑlɪʃt mɑɹbəl flɔɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn hɛɹ-θɪn ɡaʊdʒ kʌt θɹu ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ əz ə plʌm laɪn.

As the trail began to curve to the west, he felt a growing suspicion that firmed into certainty as it continued to bend. The Darkhounds had circled the camp completely, running right across the place north of the camp where several huge trees lay half toppled and propped by their neighbors, each with a tall chunk sliced cleanly out of its splintered trunk. The tracks covered a stone outcrop as smooth and flat as a polished marble floor except for one hair-thin gouge cut through it straight as a plumb line.

nʌθɪŋ ɹɪzɪstɪd ði oʊpənɪŋ ʌv ən æʃəmənz ɡeɪtweɪ, ən tu hæɾ oʊpən hɪɹ. ə θɪk paɪn ðət hæd fɔlən blɑkɪŋ wʌn hæɾ ə sɛkʃən fɔɹ peɪsɪz waɪd bɝn aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌt ðə tʃɑɹɾ ɛnz wɝ əz niɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd kʌm fɹəm ə sɔmɪl. ɪt sim ðəɾ ɛvəɾəns ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəs dɑɹkhaʊnz, haʊɛvɝ. ðə pæk hæd nɑt pɔz ðəɹ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, əɹ ivən sloʊd ðəɾ i kəd tɛl.

Nothing resisted the opening of an Asha'man's gateway, and two had opened here. A thick pine that had fallen blocking one had a section four paces wide burned out of it, but the charred ends were as neat as if they had come from a sawmill. It seemed that evidence of the One Power did not interest Darkhounds, however. The pack had not paused there any more than anywhere else, or even slowed that he could tell.

dɑɹkhaʊnz kəd ɹʌn fæstɝ ðən hɔɹsəz, ən fəɹ lɔŋɡɝ, ən ðə stɛntʃ ə ðɛm hɑɹdli sim tə hæv feɪɾəd mɔɹ ɪn wʌn pleɪs ðən ənʌðɝ. ət tu pɔɪns ɪn ðət sɝkəɾ i hæd pɪkt ʌp ə fɔɹkɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɹeɪl, bʌt ðət wɑz oʊnli ðə pæk kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ ən dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ saʊθ. wʌns ɝaʊn ðə kæmp, ən ðən ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ æftɝ wʌtɛvɝ əɹ huɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ. pleɪnli, ðət wɑz nɑt hɪm. pɝhæps ðə pæk hæd sɝkəl kəz ðeɪ sɛns hɪm, sɛnst sʌmwʌn u wɑz tɑvɝən, jɛɾ i daʊɾɪd ðət dɑɹkhaʊnz wʊɾə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd wʌn ɪnstən ət kʌmɪŋ ɪndə ðə kæmp, hæd ðeɪ bɪn æftɝ hɪm. ðə pæk i hæd feɪs bɪfɔɹ hæɾ ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi ʌv ɪljən, ðoʊ ɪt hæd nɑt tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm tɪl leɪɾɝ. bʌt dɪd dɑɹkhaʊnz ɹipɔɹt wʌt ðeɪ sɔ, ðə weɪ ɹæts ən ɹeɪvənz dɪd? ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪz dʒɔ klɛntʃ.

Darkhounds could run faster than horses, and for longer, and the stench of them hardly seemed to have faded more in one place than another. At two points in that circuit he had picked up a forking in the trail, but that was only the pack coming from the north and departing south. Once around the camp, and then on their way after whatever or whoever they were hunting. Plainly, that was not him. Perhaps the pack had circled because they sensed him, sensed someone who was ta'veren, yet he doubted that Darkhounds would have hesitated one instant at coming into the camp, had they been after him. The pack he had faced before had entered the city of Illian, though it had not tried to kill him till later. But did Darkhounds report what they saw, the way rats and ravens did? The thought made his jaw clench.

ðə ʃædoʊz ətɛnʃən wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛni seɪn mæn fɪɹd, ðə ʃædoʊz ətɛnʃən maɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð fɹiɪŋ feɪl. ðət kənsɝn ɪm mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. jɛt ðəɹ wɝ weɪz tə faɪt ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, weɪz tə faɪt ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðæt. wʌtɛvɝ keɪm bɪtwin ɪm ən feɪl, dɑɹkhaʊnz əɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, hi wəd faɪn ə weɪ tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn əɹ θɹu, wɪtʃɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. ə mæn kəɾ oʊnli hæv soʊ mʌtʃ fɪɹ ɪn ɪm ət wʌn taɪm, ən ɔl ə hɪz fɪɹ wɑz sɛntɝɾ ɑn feɪl. ðəɹ dʒʌst wɑz noʊ ɹum fəɹ ɛni mɔɹ.

The Shadow's attention was something any sane man feared, the Shadow's attention might interfere with freeing Faile. That concerned him more than anything else. Yet there were ways to fight Shadowspawn, ways to fight the Forsaken, if it came to that. Whatever came between him and Faile, Darkhounds or the Forsaken or anything else, he would find a way to go around or through, whichever was necessary. A man could only have so much fear in him at one time, and all of his fear was centered on Faile. There just was no room for any more.

bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɪz stɑɹɾɪŋ pleɪs əɡɛn, ðə bɹizɪz bɹɔɾ ɪm ðə smɛlz ə pipəl ən hɔɹsəz, ʃɑɹp ɪn ði aɪsi koʊld, ən i ɹeɪn stɛpɝ tə ə sloʊ wɔk, ən ðən tə ə hɔlt. hi hæd spɑɾəd səm fɪfti əɹ sɪksti hɔɹsəz nɪɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əhɛd. ðə sʌn hæd faɪnəli pikt əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən ən bɪɡʌn tə sɛnd ʃɑɹpli slæntəd ʃæfs ə laɪt θɹu ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi, ɹəflɛktɪŋ ɔf ðə snoʊ ən lɛsənɪŋ ðə ɡlum ə lɪɾəl, ðoʊ dip, dæpəld ʃædoʊz ɹɪmeɪn bɪtwin ðə sʌnz slɛndɝ fɪŋɡɝz.

Before he reached his starting place again, the breezes brought him the smells of people and horses, sharp in the icy cold, and he reined Stepper to a slow walk, and then to a halt. He had spotted some fifty or sixty horses near a hundred paces ahead. The sun had finally peeked above the horizon and begun to send sharply slanted shafts of light through the forest canopy, reflecting off the snow and lessening the gloom a little, though deep, dappled shadows remained between the sun's slender fingers.

səm ə ðoʊz ʃædoʊz ɛnvɛləp hɪm. ðə maʊntəd pɑɹɾi wɑz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd fɝst sin ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz' tʃɹæks, ən i kəd si ɛɹæmz sɪkli ɡɹin kloʊk ən ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt, ðə tɪŋkɝ ɡɑɹməns dʒɑɹɪŋ wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. moʊst ə ðə ɹaɪɾɝz wɔɹ ɹɪmd ɹɛd hɛlməts ʃeɪp laɪk pɑts ən dɑɹk kloʊks oʊvɝ ɹɛd bɹɛstpleɪts, ən ðə lɔŋ ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðɛɹ lænsɪz stɝɾ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɛɹz əz ðə soʊlʒɝz tʃɹaɪd tə kip wɑtʃ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ðə fɝst ə min ɔfən ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋz, wɪð ə suɾəbəl bɑɾiɡɑɹd ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz.

Some of those shadows enveloped him. The mounted party was not far from where he had first seen the Darkhounds' tracks, and he could see Aram's sickly green cloak and red-striped coat, the Tinker garments jarring with the sword on his back. Most of the riders wore rimmed red helmets shaped like pots and dark cloaks over red breastplates, and the long red streamers on their lances stirred in the light airs as the soldiers tried to keep watch in every direction. The First of Mayene often rode out in the mornings, with a suitable bodyguard of the Winged Guards.

hi stɑɹɾəd tə slɪp əweɪ wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə mit bɹəleɪn, bʌt ðən i sɔ θɹi tɔl wɪmən əfʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz, lɔŋ dɑɹk ʃɔlz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ən dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʌpɝ bɑɾiz, ən i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. waɪz wʌnz ɹoʊd wən ðeɪ hæd tə, ɪf ənwɪlɪŋli, bʌt tʃɹæmpɪŋ ə maɪl əɹ tu ɪn ðə snoʊ wɛɹɪŋ hɛvi wʊlən skɝts wɑz ɪnsəfɪʃən ɹizən tə fɔɹs əm ɑntu hɔɹsbæk. ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli siɑnɪɾ əɹ mɑsʊɝi wɑz ɪn ðət ɡɹup, əz wɛl, ðoʊ ði il wɪmən sim tə laɪk bɹəleɪn fəɹ səm ɹizən i kəd nɑt fæðəm.

He started to slip away without having to meet Berelain, but then he saw three tall women afoot among the horses, long dark shawls wrapped around their heads and draped over their upper bodies, and he hesitated. Wise Ones rode when they had to, if unwillingly, but tramping a mile or two in the snow wearing heavy woolen skirts was insufficient reason to force them onto horseback. Almost certainly Seonid or Masuri was in that group, as well, though the Aiel women seemed to like Berelain for some reason he could not fathom.

hi hæd noʊ θɔɾ ə dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz, noʊ mæɾɝ u wɑz wɪð ðɛm, bʌt hɛzəteɪʃən kɑst ɪm ɪz tʃæns əɾ ɪveɪʒən. wʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz - hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz kɛɹɛl, ə faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən u ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə tʃælənʒ ɪn əɹ ʃɑɹp blu aɪz - ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə pɔɪn ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, ən ðə hoʊl pɑɹɾi tɝnd, ðə soʊlʒɝz wɪpɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɝaʊn ən piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd hɪm, lænsɪz tɪpt wɪð ə fʊɾ ə stil hæf loʊɝd. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðeɪ kəd meɪk ɪm aʊt klɪɹli θɹu ðə dip pulz ə ʃædoʊ ən bɹaɪt bɑɹz ə sʌnlaɪt. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðə waɪz wʌn hæd, bʌt ðɛn, il dʒɛnɝəli hæd ʃɑɹp aɪz.

He had no thought of joining the riders, no matter who was with them, but hesitation cost him his chance at evasion. One of the Wise Ones - he thought it was Carelle, a fire-haired woman who always had a challenge in her sharp blue eyes - raised a hand to point in his direction, and the whole party turned, the soldiers whipping their horses around and peering through the trees toward him, lances tipped with a foot of steel half lowered. It was unlikely they could make him out clearly through the deep pools of shadow and bright bars of sunlight. He was surprised the Wise One had, but then, Aiel generally had sharp eyes.

mɑsʊɝi wɑz ðɛɹ, ə slɪm wʊmən ɪn ə bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd kloʊk ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə dæpəl mɛɹ, ən ənʊɹə əz wɛl, kipɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊn mɛɹ wɛl bæk bʌt mɑɹk baɪ ðə dʌzənz ə θɪn dɑɹk bɹeɪdz ðət hʌŋ fɹəm ði oʊpənɪŋ ə hɝ kaʊl. bɹəleɪn hɝsɛlf sæɾ ə slik beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ ət ðə fɔɹfɹʌnt, ə tɔl bjuɾəfəl jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ, ɪn ə ɹɛd kloʊk laɪnd wɪð blæk fɝ. ə sɪmpəl flɔ lɛsən əɹ bjuɾi, ðoʊ; ʃi wɑz nɑt feɪl. ə wɝs flɔ ɹuən ɪt, əz fɑɹ əz i wɑz kənsɝnd. hi hæd lɝn ə feɪlz kɪdnæpɪŋ fɹəm hɝ, ən ə mæsiməz kɑntækt wɪð ðə sintʃæn, bʌt nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə kæmp bɪliv ðəɾ i hæd slɛpt wɪð bɹəleɪn ɑn ðə vɛɹi naɪt feɪl wɑz teɪkən, ən ʃi hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə kɝɛk ðə teɪl. ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ðə kaɪndə stɔɹi hi kəɾ æsk əɹ tə stæn ʌp ən dɪnaɪ pʌblɪkli, jɛt ʃi cʊɾə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, toʊld əɹ meɪdz tə dɪnaɪ ɪt, ɛniθɪŋ. ɪnstɛd, bɹəleɪn hɛld əɹ saɪləns, ən əɹ meɪdz, ɡɑsəpɪŋ laɪk mæɡpaɪz, æktʃəli  fɑstɝd ðə teɪl. ðət sɔɹɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən stʌk tə ə mæn, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hi hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd bɹəleɪn sɪns ðət naɪt, ən wʊɾə əv ɹɪɾən əweɪ naʊ ivən æftɝ ðeɪ sɔ hɪm, bʌt ʃi tʊk ə hufændəl bæskət fɹəm ðə meɪɾ əkʌmpəniɪŋ hɝ, ə plʌmp wʊmən ɹæpt ɪn ə blu-ænd-ɡoʊl kloʊk, ðən spoʊk tə ði ʌðɝz ən stɑɹɾəd əɹ slik beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. əloʊn. ənʊɹə ɹeɪzd ə hæn ən kɔl sʌmθɪŋ æftɝ hɝ, bʌt bɹəleɪn nɛvɝ ɡlæns bæk. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt daʊt ʃi wəd fɑloʊ wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt, ən ðə weɪ θɪŋz wɝ, livɪŋ wəɾ oʊnli meɪk pipəl bɪliv i wɑntəd tə bi pɹaɪvət wɪð hɝ. hi dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə stɛpɝz flæŋks, minɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɪɾəl i wɑntəd tə - lɛɾ əɹ fɑloʊ hɪm bæk tə ðɛm ɪf ʃi wɑntəd - bʌt ʃi ɝdʒ ðə beɪ tə ə kæntɝ dɪspaɪt ðə ɹʌf ɡɹaʊn ən ðə snoʊ, ivən lipɪŋ ə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp, hɝ ɹɛd kloʊk floʊɪŋ aʊt bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən mɛɾ ɪm hæfweɪ. ʃi wɑz ə ɡʊd ɹaɪɾɝ, hi ədmɪɾəd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. nɑɾ əz ɡʊɾ əz feɪl, bʌt bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst.

Masuri was there, a slim woman in a bronze-colored cloak riding a dapple mare, and Annoura as well, keeping her brown mare well back but marked by the dozens of thin dark braids that hung from the opening of her cowl. Berelain herself sat a sleek bay gelding at the forefront, a tall beautiful young woman with long black hair, in a red cloak lined with black fur. A simple flaw lessened her beauty, though; she was not Faile. A worse flaw ruined it, as far as he was concerned. He had learned of Faile's kidnapping from her, and of Masema's contact with the Seanchan, but nearly everyone in the camp believed that he had slept with Berelain on the very night Faile was taken, and she had done nothing to correct the tale. It was hardly the kind of story he could ask her to stand up and deny publicly, yet she could have said something, told her maids to deny it, anything. Instead, Berelain held her silence, and her maids, gossiping like magpies, actually fostered the tale. That sort of reputation stuck to a man, in the Two Rivers. He had avoided Berelain since that night, and he would have ridden away now even after they saw him, but she took a hoophandled basket from the maid accompanying her, a plump woman wrapped in a blue-and-gold cloak, then spoke to the others and started her sleek bay gelding toward him. Alone. Annoura raised a hand and called something after her, but Berelain never glanced back. Perrin did not doubt she would follow wherever he went, and the way things were, leaving would only make people believe he wanted to be private with her. He dug his heels into Stepper's flanks, meaning to join the others no matter how little he wanted to - let her follow him back to them if she wanted - but she urged the bay to a canter despite the rough ground and the snow, even leaping a stone outcrop, her red cloak flowing out behind her, and met him halfway. She was a good rider, he admitted grudgingly. Not as good as Faile, but better than most.

"jɔɹ skaʊl ɪz kwaɪt fɪɹs," ʃi læf sɔfli əz ʃi hɔltəd ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə stɛpɝ. fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi hɛld əɹ ɹeɪnz, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə blɑk ɪm ɪf i tʃɹaɪd ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊnd. ðə wʊmən hæd noʊ ʃeɪm əɾ ɔl! "smaɪl, soʊ pipəl θɪŋk wəɹ flɝɾɪŋ." ʃi pʊʃt ðə bæskəɾ əɾ ɪm wɪð wʌn kɹɪmzən-ɡlʌv hænd. "ðɪs ʃəd meɪk jə smaɪl, ət list. aɪ hɪɹ jə fɝɡɛt tə it." hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋkəld. "æn tə wɑʃ, ɪt simz. jəɹ bɪɹd nidz tʃɹɪmɪŋ, tu. ə kɛɹwɹn, sʌmwʌt dɪʃɛvəl hʌzbən ɹɛskjuɪŋ ɪz waɪf ɪz ə ɹoʊmæntɪk fɪɡjɝ, bʌt ʃi maɪt nɑt θɪŋk soʊ wɛl ʌv ə dɝɾi ɹæɡəmfɪn. noʊ wʊmən wɪl ɛvɝ fɝɡɪv jə ɹuɪnɪŋ əɹ ɪmədʒ ə ju."

"Your scowl is quite fierce," she laughed softly as she halted right in front of Stepper. From the way she held her reins, she was ready to block him if he tried going around. The woman had no shame at all! "Smile, so people think we are flirting." She pushed the basket at him with one crimson-gloved hand. "This should make you smile, at least. I hear you forget to eat." Her nose wrinkled. "And to wash, it seems. Your beard needs trimming, too. A careworn, somewhat disheveled husband rescuing his wife is a romantic figure, but she might not think so well of a dirty ragamuffin. No woman will ever forgive you ruining her image of you."

sʌɾənli kənfjuzd, pɛɹɪn tʊk ðə bæskət, sɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɑn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, ən ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz noʊz. hi wɑz əkʌstəm tə sɝɾən smɛlz fɹəm bɹəleɪn, juʒəwəli ðoʊz ʌv ə hʌntɪŋ ʃi-wʊlf, ən i wɑz ði ɪntɛndəd pɹeɪ, bʌt tədeɪ ʃi ɡeɪv ɔf noʊ hʌntɪŋ sɛnt. nɑɾ ə wɪskɝ ʌv ɪt. ʃi smɛl peɪʃən əz stoʊn, ən əmjuzd, wɪð ʌndɝkɝəns ə fɪɹ. ðə wʊmən sɝɾənli hæd nɛvɝ bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm ðəɾ i ɹɪkɔld. ən wʌd ʃi hæv tə bi peɪʃən əbaʊt? fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, wʌd ʃi hæv tə əmjuzd əbaʊt? ə ɹɪdʒ kæt smɛlɪŋ laɪk ə læm wəd nɑɾ əv kənfaʊndɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ.

Suddenly confused, Perrin took the basket, sitting it in front of him on the tall pommel of his saddle, and unconsciously rubbed at his nose. He was accustomed to certain smells from Berelain, usually those of a hunting she-wolf, and he was the intended prey, but today she gave off no hunting scent. Not a whisker of it. She smelled patient as stone, and amused, with undercurrents of fear. The woman certainly had never been afraid of him that he recalled. And what did she have to be patient about? For that matter, what did she have to amused about? A ridge cat smelling like a lamb would not have confounded him more.

kənfjuʒən əɹ noʊ, hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld ət ði ɝoʊməz dʒɹɪftɪŋ fɹəm ðə lɪɾɪd bæskət. ɹoʊstəd wʊɾən, ənlɛs i wɑz mʌtʃ mɪsteɪkən, ən bɹɛd stɪl wɔɹm fɹəm ðə beɪkɪŋ. flaʊɝ wɑz ɪn ʃɔɹt səplaɪ, ən bɹɛɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɹɛɹ əz mit. ɪt wɑz tʃɹu ðəɾ i mɪst iɾɪŋ səm deɪz. hi ɹɪli dɪd fɝɡɛt, səmtaɪmz, ən wən i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, iɾɪŋ wɑz ə tʃɔɹ, fəɹ i hæd tə ɹʌn ðə ɡɔnlət ə lini ən bɹin əɹ bi ɡɪvən ðə koʊld ʃoʊldɝ baɪ pipəl i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð dʒʌs tə ɡɛɾ ə mil. fud ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz meɪɾ ɪz maʊθ wɔɾɝ. wəɾ ɪt bi dɪslɔɪəl tə it fud bɹɔt baɪ bɹəleɪn? "θæŋk jə fəɹ ðə loʊf ən ðə wʊɾən," hi sɛd ɹʌfli, "bʌt ðə læs θɪŋ ɑn ɝθ aɪ wɑn ɪz fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk wɝ flɝɾɪŋ. ən aɪ wɑʃ wən aɪ kæn, ɪf ɪts ɛni ʌv jəɹ bɪznəs. ɪɾ ɪzən izi ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ. bɪsaɪdz, noʊbɑdi ɛls smɛlz ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ du." ʃi dɪd, hi ɹilaɪz sʌɾənli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hɪn ə swɛɾ əɹ dɝɾ ʌndɝ əɹ laɪt, flaʊɝi pɝfjum. ɪɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɪm ðəɾ i hæd noʊɾəst ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ pɝfjum, əɹ ðət ʃi smɛl klin. ɪt simd ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl.

Confusion or no, his stomach rumbled at the aromas drifting from the lidded basket. Roasted woodhen, unless he was much mistaken, and bread still warm from the baking. Flour was in short supply, and bread almost as rare as meat. It was true that he missed eating some days. He really did forget, sometimes, and when he remembered, eating was a chore, for he had to run the gauntlet of Lini and Breane or be given the cold shoulder by people he had grown up with just to get a meal. Food right under his nose made his mouth water. Would it be disloyal to eat food brought by Berelain? "Thank you for the loaf and the woodhen," he said roughly, "but the last thing on earth I want is for anyone to think we're flirting. And I wash when I can, if it's any of your business. It isn't easy in this weather. Besides, nobody else smells any better than I do." She did, he realized suddenly. There was no hint of sweat or dirt under her light, flowery perfume. It irritated him that he had noticed she was wearing perfume, or that she smelled clean. It seemed a betrayal.

bɹəleɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd moʊməntɛɹəli ɪn stɑɹɾəlmənt - waɪ? - bʌt ðən ʃi saɪd θɹu hɝ smaɪl, wɪtʃ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə lʊk fɪkst, ən ə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən ɛntɝɾ əɹ sɛnt. "hæv jəɹ tɛn sɛɾ ʌp. aɪ noʊ ðɛɹz ə ɡʊd kɑpɝ bæθtəb ɪn wʌn ə jəɹ kɑɹts. jə woʊn əv θɹoʊn ðəɾ aʊt.

Berelain's eyes widened momentarily in startlement - why? - but then she sighed through her smile, which was beginning to look fixed, and a thread of irritation entered her scent. "Have your tent set up. I know there's a good copper bathtub in one of your carts. You won't have thrown that out.

pipəl ɪkspɛkt ə noʊbəl tə lʊk laɪk ə noʊbəl, pɛɹɪn, ən ðəɾ ɪnkludz biɪŋ pɹəzɛntəbəl, ivən wən ɪt teɪks ɛkstʃɹə ɛfɝt. ɪts ə bɑɹɡən bɪtwin jə ən ðɛm. jə mʌst ɡɪv əm wʌt ðeɪ ɪkspɛkt əz wɛl əz wʌt ðeɪ niɾ əɹ wɑnt, əɹ ðeɪ luz ɹɪspɛkt ən stɑɹt ɹɪzɛntɪŋ jə fəɹ meɪkɪŋ əm luz ɪt. fɹæŋkli, nʌn ʌv əs kən əfɔɹd fəɹ jə tə lɛt ðət hæpən.

People expect a noble to look like a noble, Perrin, and that includes being presentable, even when it takes extra effort. It's a bargain between you and them. You must give them what they expect as well as what they need or want, or they lose respect and start resenting you for making them lose it. Frankly, none of us can afford for you to let that happen.

wɝ ɔl fɑɹ fɹəm əɹ hoʊmz, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɛnəmiz, ən aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ bɪliv ðət ju, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz, meɪ bi əɹ oʊnli tʃæns ə lɪvɪŋ tə ɹitʃ əɹ hoʊmz əɡɛn. wɪθaʊt ju, ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɔlz əpɑɹt. naʊ smaɪl, kəz ɪf wɝ flɝɾɪŋ, ðən wi ɑɹən tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls." pɛɹɪn bɛɹɾ ɪz tiθ. ðə minɝz ən ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌɾ ət fɪfti peɪsɪz, ɪn ðɪs ɡlum, ɪt wəd bi teɪkən fəɹ ə smaɪl. luz ɹɪspɛkt? bɹəleɪn hæd hɛlp stʃɹɪp ɪm ʌv ɛni ɹɪspɛkt i wʌns hæd fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk, nɑt tə mɛnʃən feɪlz sɝvəns. wɝs, feɪl hæd ɡɪvən ɪm səm vɝʒən ə ðət lɛktʃɝ əbaʊɾ ə noʊbəlz duɾi tə ɡɪv pipəl wʌt ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd mɔɹ ðən wʌns. wʌt bi ɹizɛntəd wɑz hɪɹɪŋ ðɪs wʊmən, ʌv ɔl pipəl, ɛkoʊ hɪz waɪf. "wʌɾ ɑɹ wi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, ðɛn, ðət jə doʊn tʃɹʌs jəɹ oʊn pipəl tə noʊ?"

We're all far from our homes, surrounded by enemies, and I very much believe that you, Lord Perrin Goldeneyes, may be our only chance of living to reach our homes again. Without you, everything falls apart. Now smile, because if we're flirting, then we aren't talking about something else." Perrin bared his teeth. The Mayeners and the Wise Ones were watching, but at fifty paces, in this gloom, it would be taken for a smile. Lose respect? Berelain had helped strip him of any respect he once had from the Two Rivers folk, not to mention Faile's servants. Worse, Faile had given him some version of that lecture about a noble's duty to give people what they expected more than once. What be resented was hearing this woman, of all people, echo his wife. "What are we talking about, then, that you don't trust your own people to know?"

hɝ feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð ən smaɪlɪŋ, jɛt ði ʌndɝkɝən ə fɪɹ ɪn əɹ sɛn stʃɹɛŋθənd. ɪt wɑz noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ pænɪk, bʌt ʃi bɪliv hɝsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ. hɝ ɡlʌv hænz wɝ taɪɾ ɑn ðə beɪz ɹeɪnz. "aɪv hæd maɪ θif-kætʃɝz noʊzɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn mæsiməz kæmp, meɪkɪŋ 'fɹɛnz.' nɑɾ əz ɡʊɾ əz hævɪŋ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ðɛɹ, bʌt ðeɪ tʊk waɪn ðeɪ səpoʊzədli stoʊl fɹəm mi, ən ðeɪ lɝn ə lɪɾəl baɪ lɪsnɪŋ." fəɹ ən ɪnstənt ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm kwɪtsɪkli, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd. laɪt! ʃi nu feɪl juz sɛlən ən ðoʊz ʌðɝ ɪɾiəts əz spaɪz! ɪt hæd bɪn bɹəleɪn u toʊld ɪm əbaʊɾ əm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

Her face remained smooth and smiling, yet the undercurrent of fear in her scent strengthened. It was nowhere near panic, but she believed herself in danger. Her gloved hands were tight on the bay's reins. "I've had my thief-catchers nosing about in Masema's camp, making 'friends.' Not as good as having eyes-and-ears there, but they took wine they supposedly stole from me, and they learned a little by listening." For an instant she regarded him quizzically, tilting her head. Light! She knew Faile used Selande and those other idiots as spies! It had been Berelain who told him about them in the first place.

laɪkli dʒɛnʒɹ ən sɑns, hɝ θifkætʃɝz, hæd sin hɑviɑɹ ən nɛɹiən ɪn mæsiməz kæmp. beɪlwɝ wəɾ əv tə bi wɔɹn bɪfɔɹ i tʃɹaɪd tə sɛt mɛdɔɹ ɑn bɹəleɪn ən ənʊɹə. ðət wəd sɝɾənli meɪk ə faɪn tæŋɡəl. wən i sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ʃi wɛn ɑn. "aɪ pʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðət bæskət bɪsaɪdz bɹɛɾ ən ə wʊɾən. ə . . . dɑkjəmɛnt . . . ðət sɑns faʊn ɝli jɛstɝdeɪ, lɑkt əweɪ ɪn mæsiməz kæmp dɛsk. ðə ful nɛvɝ sɔ ə lɑk wɪθaʊt wɑntɪŋ tə noʊ wʌɾ ɪt hɪd. ɪf i hæd tə mɛɾəl wɪð wʌt mæsimə kɛpt ʌndɝ lɑk ən ki, hi ʃʊɾə mɛmɝaɪz ðə θɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ə teɪkɪŋ ɪt, bʌt wʌts dʌn ɪz dʌn. doʊn lɛɾ ɛniwʌn si jə ɹiɾɪŋ ɪɾ æftɝ aɪ wɛn tə ɔl ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl tə haɪɾ ɪt!" ʃi æɾəd ʃɑɹpli əz i lɪftəd ðə bæskəts lɪd, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə klɔθ-ɹæp bʌndəl ən ɹilisɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ smɛlz ə ɹoʊstəd bɝɾ ən wɔɹm bɹɛd. "aɪv sin mæsiməz mɛn fɑloʊɪŋ jə bɪfɔɹ. ðeɪ kəd bi wɑtʃɪŋ naʊ!" "aɪm nɑɾ ə ful," hi ɡɹaʊld. hi nu əbaʊt mæsiməz wɑtʃɝz. moʊst ə ðə mænz fɑloʊɝz wɝ taʊnsmɪn, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst ɑkwɝɾ ɪnʌf ɪn ðə wʊdz tə ʃeɪm ə tɛn-jɪɹ-oʊl bæk hoʊm.

Likely Gendar and Santes, her thiefcatchers, had seen Haviar and Nerion in Masema's camp. Balwer would have to be warned before he tried to set Medore on Berelain and Annoura. That would certainly make a fine tangle. When he said nothing, she went on. "I put something in that basket besides bread and a woodhen. A . . . document . . . that Santes found early yesterday, locked away in Masema's camp desk. The fool never saw a lock without wanting to know what it hid. If he had to meddle with what Masema kept under lock and key, he should have memorized the thing instead of taking it, but what's done is done. Don't let anyone see you reading it after I went to all this trouble to hide it!" she added sharply as he lifted the basket's lid, revealing a cloth-wrapped bundle and releasing stronger smells of roasted bird and warm bread. "I've seen Masema's men following you before. They could be watching now!" "I'm not a fool," he growled. He knew about Masema's watchers. Most of the man's followers were townsmen, and most of the rest awkward enough in the woods to shame a ten-year-old back home.

wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt tə seɪ wʌn əɹ tu maɪt nɑt bi haɪɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə spaɪ fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə ʃædoʊz. ðeɪ ɔlweɪz kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns, sɪns ɪz aɪz meɪɾ əm bɪliv i wɑz səm sɔɹɾ ə hæf-teɪm ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, soʊ hi sɛldəm dɪtɛktəd ðɛɹ sɛns, ən i hæd hæɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɑn ɪz maɪn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ.

Which was not to say one or two might not be hiding somewhere among the trees close enough to spy from among the shadows. They always kept their distance, since his eyes made them believe he was some sort of half-tame Shadowspawn, so he seldom detected their scents, and he had had other things on his mind this morning.

fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə klɔθ əsaɪd tə ɪkspoʊz ðə wʊɾən, ɔlmoʊst əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə fɛɹ-saɪz tʃɪkən, wɪð ɪts skɪn kɹɪspli bɹaʊnd, hi tɔɹ ɔf wʌn ə ðə bɝdz lɛɡz waɪl filɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə bʌndəl ən slaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə pis ə hɛvi, kɹim-kʌlɝd peɪpɝ foʊldəɾ ɪn fɔɹ. kɛɹləs ʌv ɡɹis-spɑts, hi ənfoʊldəd ðə peɪpɝ ətɑp ðə bɝd, ə lɪɾəl klʌmsəli ɪn ɪz ɡɔnləts, ən ɹɛd waɪl nɪbəlɪŋ ɑn ðə lɛɡ. tə ɛvɹiwʌn wɑtʃɪŋ, hi wəɾ əpɪɹ tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ wʌt pɑɹɾ ə ðə wʊɾən tə ətæk nɛkst. ə θɪk ɡɹin wæks sil, kɹækt ɑn wʌn saɪd, hɛld ən ɪmpɹɛʃən ʌv wʌɾ i dɪsaɪɾɪd wɝ θɹi hænz, itʃ wɪð ðə fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ ən lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ ɹeɪzd ən ði ʌðɝz foʊldəd. ðə lɛɾɝz ɹɪɾən ɑn ðə peɪpɝ ɪn ə floʊɪŋ skɹɪpt wɝ ɑdli fɔɹmd, səm ənɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl, bʌt ðə θɪŋ wɑz ɹiɾəbəl wɪð ə lɪɾəl ɛfɝt.

Fingering the cloth aside to expose the woodhen, almost as large as a fair-sized chicken, with its skin crisply browned, he tore off one of the bird's legs while feeling under the bundle and sliding out a piece of heavy, cream-colored paper folded in four. Careless of grease-spots, he unfolded the paper atop the bird, a little clumsily in his gauntlets, and read while nibbling on the leg. To everyone watching, he would appear to be studying what part of the woodhen to attack next. A thick green wax seal, cracked on one side, held an impression of what he decided were three hands, each with the forefinger and little finger raised and the others folded. The letters written on the paper in a flowing script were oddly formed, some unrecognizable, but the thing was readable with a little effort.

ðə bɛɹɝ ə ðɪs stænz ʌndɝ maɪ pɝsənəl pɹətɛkʃən. ɪn ðə neɪm ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ɡɪv ɪm wʌtɛvɝ eɪɾ i ɹikwaɪɝz ɪn sɝvəs tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ ən spik ʌv ɪt tə nʌn bʌt mi.

The bearer of this stands under my personal protection. In the name of the Empress, may she live forever, give him whatever aid he requires in service to the Empire and speak of it to none but me.

baɪ hɝ sil sjuɹɔθ səbəl mɛlʒɹəθ ʌv æsɪnbɑɹ ən bɑɹsɑbə haɪ leɪɾi "ði ɛmpɹɛs," hi sɛd sɔfli, sɑf laɪk aɪɝn bɹʌʃɪŋ sɪlk. kɑnfɝmeɪʃən ə mæsiməz dilɪŋz wɪð ðə sintʃæn, ðoʊ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, hi hæd niɾəd nʌn. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ bɹəleɪn wʊɾə laɪɾ əbaʊt. sjuɹɔθ səbəl mɛlʒɹəθ mʌs bi sʌmwʌn ɪmpɔɹɾənt, tə bi hændɪŋ aʊt ðɪs kaɪndə dɑkjəmɛnt. "ðɪs wɪl fɪnɪʃ hɪm, wʌns sɑns tɛstəfaɪd wɛɹ i faʊn ɪt." sɝvəs tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ?

By her seal Suroth Sabelle Meldarath of Asinbayar and Barsabba High Lady "The Empress," he said softly, soft like iron brushing silk. Confirmation of Masema's dealings with the Seanchan, though for himself, he had needed none. It was not the sort of thing Berelain would have lied about. Suroth Sabelle Meldarath must be someone important, to be handing out this kind of document. "This will finish him, once Santes testified where he found it." Service to the Empire?

mæsimə nu ɹænd hæd fɔt ðə sintʃæn! ðət ɹeɪnboʊ bɝst ɪndə hɪz hɛd, ən wɑz swɛpt əweɪ. ðə mæn wɑz ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ! bɹəleɪn læft əz ɪf i hæd sɛd sʌmθɪŋ wɪɾi, bʌɾ əɹ smaɪl dɛfənətli lʊk fɔɹst, naʊ. "sɑns toʊl mi noʊ wʌn sɔ hɪm ɪn ðə bʌsəl ə sɛɾɪŋ ʌp kæmp, soʊ aɪ əlaʊɾ ɪm ən dʒɛnʒɹ tə ɡoʊ bæk wɪð maɪ læs kæsk ʌv ɡʊd tuneɪɡən. ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə ɹɪtɝn baɪ ən aʊɝ æftɝ dɑɹk, bʌt niðɝ hæz. aɪ səpoʊz ðeɪ kəd bi slipɪŋ ɪɾ ɔf, bʌt ðeɪv nɛvɝ - " ʃi bɹoʊk ɔf wɪð ə stɑɹɾəld saʊnd, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ən i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd bɪɾən ðə θaɪboʊn ɪn hæf. laɪt, hi hæd stʃɹɪpt ɔl ðə flɛʃ fɹəm ðə lɛɡ wɪθaʊt noʊɾɪsɪŋ. "aɪm hʌŋɡɹiɝ ðən aɪ θɔt," hi mʌɾɝd.

Masema knew Rand had fought the Seanchan! That rainbow burst into his head, and was swept away. The man was a traitor! Berelain laughed as if he had said something witty, but her smile definitely looked forced, now. "Santes told me no one saw him in the bustle of setting up camp, so I allowed him and Gendar to go back with my last cask of good Tunaighan. They were supposed to return by an hour after dark, but neither has. I suppose they could be sleeping it off, but they've never - " She broke off with a startled sound, staring at him, and he realized that he had bitten the thighbone in half. Light, he had stripped all the flesh from the leg without noticing. "I'm hungrier than I thought," he muttered.

spɪɾɪŋ ðə nʌb ə boʊn ɪndə ðə pɑm ə hɪz ɡɔnlət, hi dʒɹɑp ðə pisəz tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "ɪts seɪf tə əsum mæsimə noʊz juv ðɪs. aɪ hoʊp jəɹ kipɪŋ ə hɛvi ɡɑɹɾ ɝaʊn jə ɔl ðə taɪm, nɑt dʒʌst wən jə ɹaɪɾ aʊt." "ɡælɛn əz fɪfti mɛn slipɪŋ ɝaʊn maɪ tɛn əz ə læs naɪt," ʃi sɛd, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ, ən i saɪd. jə wəd θɪŋk ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛnibəɾi baɪɾ ə boʊn ɪn tu bɪfɔɹ. "wʌɾ əz ənʊɹə toʊl ju?"

Spitting the nub of bone into the palm of his gauntlet, he dropped the pieces to the ground. "It's safe to assume Masema knows you have this. I hope you're keeping a heavy guard around you all the time, not just when you ride out." "Gallenne has fifty men sleeping around my tent as of last night," she said, still staring, and he sighed. You would think she had never seen anybody bite a bone in two before. "What has Annoura told you?"

"ʃi wɑntəd mi tə ɡɪv ɪt tə hɝ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ, soʊ ɪf aɪ wɑz æskt, aɪ kəd seɪ aɪ dɪdn əv ɪɾ ən dɪdnt noʊ wɛɹ ɪt wɑz, ən ʃi kəd səpɔɹt maɪ wɝd. aɪ daʊt ðət wəd sæɾəsfaɪ mæsimə, ðoʊ."

"She wanted me to give it to her to destroy, so if I was asked, I could say I didn't have it and didn't know where it was, and she could support my word. I doubt that would satisfy Masema, though."

"noʊ, aɪ daʊɾ ɪt wʊd." ənʊɹə hæd tə noʊ ðæt, tu. ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd bi ɹɔŋhɛɾɪd, əɹ ivən fulɪʃ əpɑn əkeɪʒən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ stupəd. "dɪd ʃi seɪ ʃi wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ɪt, əɹ ðəɾ ɪf jə ɡeɪv ɪt tə hɝ, ʃi kʊd?"

"No, I doubt it would." Annoura had to know that, too. Aes Sedai could be wrongheaded, or even foolish upon occasion, but they were never stupid. "Did she say she would destroy it, or that if you gave it to her, she could?"

bɹəleɪnz bɹaʊ fɝoʊɾ ɪn θɔt, ən ɪt tʊk əɹ ə moʊmən tə seɪ, "ðæt ʃi wʊd." ðə beɪ dænst ə fju ɪmpeɪʃən stɛps, bʌt ʃi bɹɔɾ ɪm ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl izəli, wɪθaʊt peɪɪŋ ətɛnʃən. "aɪ kæn θɪŋk wʌɾ ɛls ʃi wəd wɑn ɪt fɔɹ," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ənʌðɝ pɔz. "mæsimə ɪz hɑɹdli laɪkli tə bi səsɛptəbəl tə . . . pɹɛʃɝ." blækmeɪl, ʃi mɛnt. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt si mæsimə stændɪŋ stɪl fəɹ ðəɾ iðɝ. ɪspɛʃli blækmeɪl baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Berelain's brow furrowed in thought, and it took her a moment to say, "That she would." The bay danced a few impatient steps, but she brought him under control easily, without paying attention. "I can't think what else she would want it for," she said after another pause. "Masema is hardly likely to be susceptible to . . . pressure." Blackmail, she meant. Perrin could not see Masema standing still for that either. Especially blackmail by an Aes Sedai.

ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ə tɛɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝ lɛɡ lus fɹəm ðə bɝd, hi mænədʒ tə ɹifoʊl ðə pis ə peɪpɝ ən tʌk ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz sliv, wɛɹ ɪz ɡɔnlət wəd kip ɪt fɹəm fɔlɪŋ aʊt. ɪt wɑz stɪl ɛvəɾəns. bʌɾ ʌv wʌt? haʊ kəd ðə mæn bi boʊθ ə fənæɾɪk fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ? kəɾ i hæv teɪkən ðə dɑkjəmɛn fɹəm . . . ? hu? səm kəlæbɝeɪɾɝ i hæd kæptʃɝd? bʌt waɪ wəd mæsimə kip ɪt lɑkt əweɪ ənlɛs ɪt hæd bɪn mɛn fəɹ hɪm? hi hæd mɛt wɪð sintʃæn. ən haʊ hæɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə juz ɪt? hu kəd tɛl wʌɾ ə θɪŋ ðɪs wəɾ əlaʊ ə mæn tə kɔl ɑn? pɛɹɪn saɪd hɛvəli. hi hæd tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz, ən noʊ ænsɝz. ænsɝz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə kwɪkɝ maɪn ðən hɪz. meɪbi beɪlwɝ wəɾ əv ə noʊʃən. wɪð ə teɪst ə fuɾ ɪn ɪt, hɪz stʌmək wɑntəɾ ɪm tə dɪvaʊɝ ðə lɛɡ ɪn ɪz hæn ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə bɝd tu, bʌɾ i kloʊz ðə lɪd fɝmli ən tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk mɛʒɝd baɪts. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn θɪŋ i kəd faɪn aʊt fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. "wʌɾ ɛls əz ənʊɹə sɛd? əbaʊt mæsimə." "nʌθɪŋ, bɪsaɪdz ðət hiz deɪnʒɝəs ən aɪ ʃəɾ əvɔɪd hɪm, əz ɪf aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ʃi dɪslaɪks ɪm ən tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm." ənʌðɝ bɹif hɛzəteɪʃən, ən bɹəleɪn æɾəd, "waɪ?" ðə fɝst ə min wɑz juz tə ɪntʃɹiɡz, ən ʃi lɪsən fəɹ wʌt wɑz nɑt sɛd.

Under cover of tearing the other leg loose from the bird, he managed to refold the piece of paper and tuck it into his sleeve, where his gauntlet would keep it from falling out. It was still evidence. But of what? How could the man be both a fanatic for the Dragon Reborn and a traitor? Could he have taken the document from . . . ? Who? Some collaborator he had captured? But why would Masema keep it locked away unless it had been meant for him? He had met with Seanchan. And how had he intended to use it? Who could tell what a thing this would allow a man to call on? Perrin sighed heavily. He had too many questions, and no answers. Answers required a quicker mind than his. Maybe Balwer would have a notion. With a taste of food in it, his stomach wanted him to devour the leg in his hand and the rest of the bird too, but he closed the lid firmly and tried to take measured bites. There was one thing he could find out for himself. "What else has Annoura said? About Masema." "Nothing, besides that he's dangerous and I should avoid him, as if I didn't know that already. She dislikes him and talking about him." Another brief hesitation, and Berelain added, "Why?" The First of Mayene was used to intrigues, and she listened for what was not said.

pɛɹɪn tʊk ənʌðɝ baɪt tə ɡɪv hɪmsɛlf ə moʊmənt waɪl i tʃuɾ ən swɑloʊd. hi wɑz nɑt juz tə ɪntʃɹiɡz, jɛɾ i hæd bɪn ɪkspoʊz tə ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə noʊ ðət seɪɪŋ tu mʌtʃ kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs. soʊ kəd seɪɪŋ tu lɪɾəl, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt beɪlwɝ θɔt. "ənʊɹə hæz bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð mæsimə ɪn sikɹət. soʊ hæz mɑsʊɝi."

Perrin took another bite to give himself a moment while he chewed and swallowed. He was not used to intrigues, yet he had been exposed to enough of them to know that saying too much could be dangerous. So could saying too little, no matter what Balwer thought. "Annoura has been meeting with Masema in secret. So has Masuri."

bɹəleɪnz fɪkst smaɪl ɹɪmeɪn ɪn pleɪs, bʌɾ əlɑɹm ɛntɝɾ əɹ sɛnt. ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə twɪst ɪn əɹ sæɾəl əz ɪf tə lʊk bæk ət ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən stɑp hɝsɛlf, lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps wɪð ðə tɪp ə hɝ tʌŋ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz əv ðɛɹ ɹizənz" wɑz ɔl ʃi sɛd. soʊ, wɑz ʃi əlɑɹmd oʊvɝ əɹ ædvaɪzɝ miɾɪŋ mæsimə, əɹ əlɑɹm ðət pɛɹɪn nu, əɹ . . . ? hi heɪɾəd ɔl ðiz kɑmpləkeɪʃənz. ðeɪ dʒʌst ɡɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv wʌt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. laɪt, hi hæd mænədʒ tə klin ðə sɛkən lɛɡ ɔlɹɛɾi! hoʊpɪŋ bɹəleɪn hæd nɑt noʊɾəst, hi heɪstəli tɔs ðə boʊnz əsaɪd. hɪz bɛli ɡɹaʊl fəɹ mɔɹ.

Berelain's fixed smile remained in place, but alarm entered her scent. She started to twist in her saddle as if to look back at the two Aes Sedai, and stopped herself, licking her lips with the tip of her tongue. "Aes Sedai always have their reasons" was all she said. So, was she alarmed over her advisor meeting Masema, or alarmed that Perrin knew, or . . . ? He hated all these complications. They just got in the way of what was important. Light, he had managed to clean the second leg already! Hoping Berelain had not noticed, he hastily tossed the bones aside. His belly growled for more.

hɝ pipəl hæd meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ dɪstəns, bʌɾ ɛɹæm hæd ɹɪɾən ə ʃɔɹt weɪ təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn ən wɑz linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə pɪɹ əɾ əm θɹu ðə ʃæɾoʊd tʃɹiz. ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ stændɪŋ tə wʌn saɪd tɔkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, simɪŋli ʌnəwɛɹ ðət ðeɪ wɝ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ æŋkəlz ɪn snoʊ əɹ ðət ðə koʊl bɹizɪz hæd pɪkt ʌp ɪnʌf tə flæp ðə dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɛnz ə ðɛɹ ʃɔlz. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ə ðə θɹi lʊk pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪnz weɪ, tu. noʊʃənz ə pɹaɪvəsi nɛvɝ kɛpt ə waɪz wʌn fɹəm stɪkɪŋ əɹ noʊz wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi wɑntəd. ðeɪ wɝ laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ ðət weɪ. mɑsʊɝi ən ənʊɹə wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ, tu, ðoʊ ðeɪ əpɪɹd tə bi kipɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪstəns fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ. pɛɹɪn wʊɾə weɪdʒɝd ðət wɪθaʊt ðə waɪz wʌnz ðɛɹ, boʊθ sɪstɝz wʊɾə bɪn juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ivzdʒɹɑp. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə waɪz wʌnz pɹɑbli nu haʊ tə də ðæt, tu, ən ðeɪ hæɾ əlaʊd mɑsʊɝiz vɪzəts tə mæsimə. wəɾ iðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɹæk əɹ tiθ ɪf ðeɪ sɔ ðə waɪz wʌnz lɪsnɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ? ənʊɹə simd ɔlmoʊst əz kɛɹfəl wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz əz mɑsʊɝi wɑz. laɪt, hi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ðɪs bɹaɪɝ θɪkɪt! hi hæd tə lɪv ɪn ɪt, ðoʊ. "wiv ɡɪvən tʌŋz ɪnʌf tə wæɡ oʊvɝ," hi sɛd. nɑt ðət ðeɪ niɾəd ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ hæd. hʊkɪŋ ðə bæskəts hufændəlz oʊvɝ ɪz pɑməl, hi hil stɛpɝz flæŋks. ɪt kəd hɑɹdli bi dɪslɔɪəl dʒʌs tə iɾ ə bɝd.

Her people had maintained their distance, but Aram had ridden a short way toward Perrin and Berelain and was leaning forward to peer at them through the shadowed trees. The Wise Ones were standing to one side talking among themselves, seemingly unaware that they were over their ankles in snow or that the cold breezes had picked up enough to flap the dangling ends of their shawls. Every so often one or another of the three looked Perrin and Berelain's way, too. Notions of privacy never kept a Wise One from sticking her nose wherever she wanted. They were like Aes Sedai that way. Masuri and Annoura were watching, too, though they appeared to be keeping their distance from one another. Perrin would have wagered that without the Wise Ones there, both sisters would have been using the One Power to eavesdrop. Of course, the Wise Ones probably knew how to do that, too, and they had allowed Masuri's visits to Masema. Would either Aes Sedai crack her teeth if they saw the Wise Ones listening with the Power? Annoura seemed almost as careful with the Wise Ones as Masuri was. Light, he had no time for this briar thicket! He had to live in it, though. "We've given tongues enough to wag over," he said. Not that they needed any more than they had. Hooking the basket's hoophandles over his pommel, he heeled Stepper's flanks. It could hardly be disloyal just to eat a bird.

bɹəleɪn dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ ɪmiɾiətli, jɛt bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɛɹæm, ʃi kɑɾ ʌp ən sloʊɾ əɹ beɪ bɪsaɪd hɪm. "aɪl faɪn aʊt wʌɾ ənʊɹə ɪz ʌp tə," ʃi sɛd dətɝmənədli, lʊkɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. hɝ aɪz wɝ hɑɹd. pɛɹɪn wʊɾə pɪɾid ənʊɹə, ɪf i hæd nɑt bɪn ɹɛɾi tə tʃɹaɪ ʃeɪkɪŋ ænsɝz aʊɾ ə hɝ hɪmsɛlf. bʌt ðɛn, ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛldəm niɾəd pɪɾi, ən ðeɪ sɛldəm ɡeɪv ænsɝz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɡɪv. ðə nɛkst ɪnstənt, bɹəleɪn wɑz ɔl smaɪlz ən ɡeɪəɾi əɡɛn, ðoʊ ðə sɛn ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən stɪl hʌŋ əbaʊt hɝ, ɔlmoʊs kɹʌʃɪŋ ðə fɪɹ sɛnt. "jʌŋ ɛɹæm əz bɪn tɛlɪŋ əs ɔl əbaʊt hɑɹtsbeɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðiz wʊdz wɪð ðə waɪl hʌnt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. kəɾ ɪt ɹɪli bi soʊ, dʒju θɪŋk? aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɪɹɪŋ ðoʊz teɪlz ɪn ðə nɝsɝi." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz laɪɾ ən əmjuzd ən kæɹiɪŋ. ɛɹæmz tʃiks tɝn ɹɛd, ən səm ə ðə mɛn bɪɑn ɪm læft.

Berelain did not follow immediately, yet before he reached Aram, she caught up and slowed her bay beside him. "I'll find out what Annoura is up to," she said determinedly, looking straight ahead. Her eyes were hard. Perrin would have pitied Annoura, if he had not been ready to try shaking answers out of her himself. But then, Aes Sedai seldom needed pity, and they seldom gave answers they did not want to give. The next instant, Berelain was all smiles and gaiety again, though the scent of determination still hung about her, almost crushing the fear scent. "Young Aram has been telling us all about Heartsbane riding these woods with the Wild Hunt, Lord Perrin. Could it really be so, do you think? I remember hearing those tales in the nursery." Her voice was light and amused and carrying. Aram's cheeks turned red, and some of the men beyond him laughed.

ðeɪ stɑp læfɪŋ wən pɛɹɪn ʃoʊɾ əm ðə tʃɹæks ɪn ðə stoʊn slæb.

They stopped laughing when Perrin showed them the tracks in the stone slab.

tʃæptɝ sɛvən

CHAPTER 7

blæksmɪθs pʌzəl wən ðə læftɝ kʌɾ ɔf, ɛɹæm pʊɾ ɑn ə smʌɡ ɡɹɪn, ən wɪð nʌn ə ðə fɪɹ sɛn i hæd ɡɪvən ɔf ɝliɝ. ɛniwʌn wʊɾə θɔɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin ðə tʃɹæks hɪmsɛlf ən nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz tə noʊ. noʊ wʌn peɪɾ ɛni maɪn tə hɪz smɝk, haʊɛvɝ, əɹ tə mʌtʃ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə hjudʒ dɔɡ tʃɹæks ɪmpɹɛst ɪn stoʊn, ivən pɛɹɪnz ɛkspləneɪʃən ðət ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz wɝ lɔŋ ɡɔn. ʌv kɔɹs, hi kəd nɑt tɛl əm haʊ hi nu ðæt, jɛt noʊ wʌn sim tə noʊɾəs ðə læk. wʌn ə ðə ʃɑɹpli slæntɪŋ bɑɹz ə ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt wɑz fɔlɪŋ dɝɛkli ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪ slæb, ɪluməneɪɾɪŋ ɪt klɪɹli. stɛpɝ hæd ɡɹoʊn əkʌstəm tə ðə feɪɾɪŋ bɝnt-sʌlfɝ smɛl - ət list i oʊnli snɔɹɾɪd ən leɪd bæk ɪz ɪɹz - bʌt ði ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz ʃaɪɾ ət ðə tɪltəd stoʊn. nʌn ə ðə hjumənz ɪksɛpt pɛɹɪn kəd dɪtɛk ðət smɛl, ən moʊst ɡɹaʊld oʊvɝ ðɛɹ maʊns' fɹækʃəs bɪheɪvjɝ ən pɪɹɾ ət ði ɑdli mɑɹk stoʊn əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə kjʊɹiɑsəɾi dɪspleɪd baɪ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ.

Blacksmith's Puzzle When the laughter cut off, Aram put on a smug grin, and with none of the fear scent he had given off earlier. Anyone would have thought he had already seen the tracks himself and knew everything there was to know. No one paid any mind to his smirk, however, or to much of anything except the huge dog tracks impressed in stone, even Perrin's explanation that the Darkhounds were long gone. Of course, he could not tell them how he knew that, yet no one seemed to notice the lack. One of the sharply slanting bars of early morning light was falling directly on the gray slab, illuminating it clearly. Stepper had grown accustomed to the fading burnt-sulphur smell - at least he only snorted and laid back his ears - but the other horses shied at the tilted stone. None of the humans except Perrin could detect that smell, and most growled over their mounts' fractious behavior and peered at the oddly marked stone as if it were a curiosity displayed by a traveling show.

bɹəleɪnz plʌmp meɪd skɹimd wən ʃi sɔ ðə tʃɹæks, ən sweɪɾ ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə fɔlɪŋ ɔf əɹ ɹaʊnd-bɛlid, nɝvəsli dænsɪŋ mɛɹ, bʌt bɹəleɪn mɪɹli æskt ənʊɹə ɪn ən æbsən fæʃən tə lʊk æftɝ əɹ ən stɛɹɾ ət ðə pɹɪns wɪð əz lɪɾəl ɪkspɹɛʃən əz ɪf ʃi hɝsɛlf wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɝ hænz taɪɾənd ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz, ðoʊ, əntɪl ðə θɪn ɹɛd lɛðɝ peɪld əkɹɔs əɹ nʌkəlz. bɝteɪn ɡælɛn, ðə lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, hɪz ɹɛd hɛlməɾ ɪmbɔst wɪð wɪŋz ən bɛɹɪŋ θɹi θɪn kɹɪmzən plumz, hæd pɝsənəl kəmæn ə bɹəleɪnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən i fɔɹst ɪz tɔl blæk ɡɛldɪŋ kloʊs tə ðə stoʊn, swɪŋɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ɪn ni-dip snoʊ ən ɹimuvɪŋ ɪz hɛlmət tə fɹaʊn ət ðə stoʊn slæb wɪð ɪz wʌn aɪ. ə skɑɹlət lɛðɝ pætʃ kʌvɝd ði ɛmpti sɑkəɾ ə ði ʌðɝ, ðə stʃɹæp kʌɾɪŋ θɹu hɪz ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ. hɪz ɡɹɪmɑs sɛɾ i sɔ tʃɹʌbəl, bʌɾ i ɔlweɪz sɔ ðə wɝs pɑsəbɪləɾiz fɝst. pɛɹɪn səpoʊz ðət wɑz bɛɾɝ ɪn ə soʊlʒɝ ðən ɔlweɪz siɪŋ ðə bɛst.
