Berelain's plump maid screamed when she saw the tracks, and swayed on the point of falling off her round-bellied, nervously dancing mare, but Berelain merely asked Annoura in an absent fashion to look after her and stared at the prints with as little expression as if she herself were Aes Sedai. Her hands tightened on her reins, though, until the thin red leather paled across her knuckles. Bertain Gallenne, the Lord Captain of the Winged Guards, his red helmet embossed with wings and bearing three thin crimson plumes, had personal command of Berelain's bodyguard this morning, and he forced his tall black gelding close to the stone, swinging down from his saddle in knee-deep snow and removing his helmet to frown at the stone slab with his one eye. A scarlet leather patch covered the empty socket of the other, the strap cutting through his shoulder-length gray hair. His grimace said he saw trouble, but he always saw the worst possibilities first. Perrin supposed that was better in a soldier than always seeing the best.

mɑsʊɝi dɪsmaʊntɪd, tu, bʌt noʊ sunɝ wɑz ʃi ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ðən ʃi pɔzd wɪð əɹ dæpəlz ɹeɪnz ɪn wʌn ɡlʌv hænd, lʊkɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli təwɔɹd ðə θɹi sʌn-dɑɹk il wɪmən. ə fju ʌv ðə minɝ soʊlʒɝz mʌɾɝd ənizəli ət ðæt, jɛt ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn juz tə ɪt baɪ naʊ. ənʊɹə hɪɾ əɹ feɪs dipɝ ɪn əɹ ɡɹeɪ hʊɾ əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə si ðə ɹɑk ən ɡeɪv bɹəleɪnz meɪɾ ə bɹɪsk ʃeɪk; ðə wʊmən ɡɑɡəld əɾ əɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. mɑsʊɝi, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, weɪɾəd bɪsaɪɾ əɹ mɛɹ wɪð ən əpɪɹəns ə peɪʃəns, spɔɪld oʊnli baɪ smuðɪŋ ðə ɹʌsət skɝts ə hɝ sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs əz ðoʊ ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. ðə waɪz wʌnz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd saɪlənt ɡlænsɪz, ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz sɪstɝz ðɛmsɛlvz. kɛɹɛl stʊɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə nəvɛɝɪn, ə skɪni ɡɹin-aɪd wʊmən, ən ɑn ði ʌðɝ mɑɹlaɪn, wɪð aɪz ə twaɪlaɪt blu ən dɑɹk hɛɹ, ɹɛɹ əmʌŋ il, nɑt kʌvɝd kəmplitli wɪð əɹ ʃɔl. ɔl θɹi wɝ tɔl wɪmən, əz tɔl əz səm mɛn, ən nʌn lʊk mɔɹ ðən ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən pɛɹɪn, bʌt noʊ wʌn cʊɾə mænədʒ ðət kɑm sɛlf-əʃʊɹəns wɪθaʊt mɔɹ jɪɹz ðən ðɛɹ feɪsəz kleɪmd.

Masuri dismounted, too, but no sooner was she on the ground than she paused with her dapples reins in one gloved hand, looking uncertainly toward the three sun-dark Aiel women. A few of the Mayener soldiers muttered uneasily at that, yet they should have been used to it by now. Annoura hid her face deeper in her gray hood as if she did not want to see the rock and gave Berelain's maid a brisk shake; the woman goggled at her in astonishment. Masuri, on the other hand, waited beside her mare with an appearance of patience, spoiled only by smoothing the russet skirts of her silk riding dress as though unaware of what she was doing. The Wise Ones exchanged silent glances, expressionless as sisters themselves. Carelle stood on one side of Nevarin, a skinny green-eyed woman, and on the other Marline, with eyes of twilight blue and dark hair, rare among Aiel, not covered completely with her shawl. All three were tall women, as tall as some men, and none looked more than a few years older than Perrin, but no one could have managed that calm self-assurance without more years than their faces claimed.

dɪspaɪt ðə lɔŋ nɛkləsɪz ən hɛvi bɹeɪslɪts ʌv ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi ðət ðeɪ wɔɹ, ðɛɹ dɑɹk hɛvi skɝts ən ðə dɑɹk ʃɔlz ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪd ðɛɹ waɪt blaʊsəz cʊɾə suɾəd fɑɹm wɪmən, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ u wɑz ɪn kəmæn bɪtwin əm ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, səmtaɪmz ðəɹ sim tə bi daʊɾ u wɑz ɪn kəmæn bɪtwin əm ən pɛɹɪn.

Despite the long necklaces and heavy bracelets of gold and ivory that they wore, their dark heavy skirts and the dark shawls that almost hid their white blouses could have suited farm women, yet there was no doubt who was in command between them and the Aes Sedai. In truth, sometimes there seemed to be doubt who was in command between them and Perrin.

faɪnəli, nəvɛɝɪn nɑɾəd. ən ɡeɪv ə wɔɹm ən əpɹuvɪŋ smaɪl. pɛɹɪn hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ sin ə smaɪl aʊɾ ə hɝ. nəvɛɝɪn dɪd nɑt wɔk ɝaʊn skaʊlɪŋ, bʌt ʃi juʒəwəli sim tə bi sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə ʌpbɹeɪd.

Finally, Nevarin nodded. And gave a warm and approving smile. Perrin had never before seen a smile out of her. Nevarin did not walk around scowling, but she usually seemed to be searching for someone to upbraid.

nɑɾ əntɪl ðət nɑd dɪd mɑsʊɝi hæn əɹ ɹeɪnz ʌp tə wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin, ən ðət hæd tə bi ðə waɪz wʌnz' duɪŋ. ɹoʊvɛɹ juʒəwəli stʌk tə hɝ laɪk ə bɝ. lɪftɪŋ əɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts, ʃi weɪɾɪd θɹu ðə snoʊ, dipɝ ðə kloʊsɝ tə ðə stoʊn ʃi keɪm, ən bɪɡæn pæsɪŋ əɹ hænz əbʌv ðə fʊtpɹɪns, ɑbviəsli tʃænəlɪŋ, ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ hæpən ðət pɛɹɪn kəd si.

Not until that nod did Masuri hand her reins up to one of the soldiers. Her Warder was nowhere to be seen, and that had to be the Wise Ones' doing. Rovair usually stuck to her like a burr. Lifting her divided skirts, she waded through the snow, deeper the closer to the stone she came, and began passing her hands above the footprints, obviously channeling, though nothing happened that Perrin could see.

ðə waɪz wʌnz wɑtʃt əɹ kloʊsli, bʌt ðɛn, mɑsʊɝiz wivz wɝ vɪzəbəl tə ðɛm. ənʊɹə dɪspleɪd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst. ði ɛnz ə ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝz nɛɹoʊ bɹeɪdz twɪtʃt əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hʊd, ən ʃi muvd əɹ hɔɹs bæk fɹəm ðə meɪd, wɛl aʊɾ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz' laɪn ə saɪt, ðoʊ ðət tʊk əɹ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm bɹəleɪn, hu ɛniwʌn kəd θɪŋk maɪt wɑn əɹ ædvaɪs naʊ. ənʊɹə ɹɪli dɪɾ əvɔɪd ðə waɪz wʌnz əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kʊd.

The Wise Ones watched her closely, but then, Masuri's weaves were visible to them. Annoura displayed no interest. The ends of the Gray sister's narrow braids twitched as if she were shaking her head inside her hood, and she moved her horse back from the maid, well out of the Wise Ones' line of sight, though that took her farther from Berelain, who anyone could think might want her advice now. Annoura really did avoid the Wise Ones as much as she could.

"faɪɝsaɪd stɔɹiz wɔkɪŋ," ɡælɛn mʌɾɝd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə stoʊn wɪð ə saɪdweɪz ɡlæns ət mɑsʊɝi. ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi ɑnɝd, jɛt fju mɛn wɑntəd tə bi kloʊs tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ. "ðoʊ aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd ɛnimɔɹ æftɝ wʌɾ aɪv sin sɪns livɪŋ min." ɪntɛn ɑn ðə tʃɹæks, mɑsʊɝi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs hɪm.

"Fireside stories walking," Gallenne muttered, drawing his gelding away from the stone with a sideways glance at Masuri. Aes Sedai, he honored, yet few men wanted to be close to an Aes Sedai who was channeling. "Though I don't know why I'm surprised anymore after what I've seen since leaving Mayene." Intent on the tracks, Masuri did not seem to notice him.

ə stɝ ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə maʊntəd lænsɝz, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv ðɛɹ oʊn aɪz əntɪl ðɛɹ kəmændɝ ɡeɪv kɑnfɝmeɪʃən, ən səm ə ðɛm bɪɡæn tə smɛl ʌv ənizi fɪɹ, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ dɑɹkhaʊnz tə lip aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt pɪk aʊɾ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz əmʌŋ soʊ mɛni wɪð ɛni iz, bʌt ðə dʒɪɾɝi ɹæŋknəs wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪt hæd tə kʌm fɹəm mɔɹ ðən ə fju.

A stir rippled through the mounted lancers, as though they had not really believed their own eyes until their commander gave confirmation, and some of them began to smell of uneasy fear, as if expecting Darkhounds to leap out of the shadows. Perrin could not pick out individuals among so many with any ease, but the jittery rankness was strong enough that it had to come from more than a few.

ɡælɛn sim tə sɛns wʌt pɛɹɪn smɛld; hi hæɾ ɪz fɔls, bʌɾ i hæd kəmændəd soʊlʒɝz fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. hæŋɪŋ ɪz hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz lɔŋ sɔɹd hɪlt, hi ɡɹɪnd. ði aɪpætʃ ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə ɡɹɪm kwɑləɾi, ə mæn u kəd si ə dʒoʊk ɪn ðə feɪs ə dɛθ ən ɪkspɛktəɾ ʌðɝz tə si ɪt, tu. "ɪf ðə blæk dɑɡz bɑðɝ ʌs, wɪl sɔl ðɛɹ ɪɹz," hi ənaʊnst ɪn ə laʊɾ ən hɑɹɾi vɔɪs. "ðæts wʌt jə də ɪn ðə stɔɹiz, ɪzən ɪt? spɹɪŋkəl sɔlt ɑn ðɛɹ ɪɹz, ən ðeɪ vænɪʃ." ə fju ʌv ðə lænsɝz læft, ðoʊ ðə miæzmə ʌv fɪɹ dɪd nɑt lɛsən əpɹiʃəbli. stɔɹiz toʊl baɪ ðə faɪɝ wɝ wʌn θɪŋ, ðoʊz seɪm stɔɹiz wɔkɪŋ ɪn ðə flɛʃ kwaɪɾ ənʌðɝ. ɡælɛn lɛɾ ɪz blæk tə bɹəleɪn ən ɹɛstəɾ ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn ɑn əɹ beɪz nɛk. hi ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə kənsɪɾɝɪŋ lʊk ðət pɛɹɪn ɹɪtɝn lɛvəli, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə teɪk ðə hɪnt.

Gallenne seemed to sense what Perrin smelled; he had his faults, but he had commanded soldiers for a long time. Hanging his helmet on his long sword hilt, he grinned. The eyepatch gave it a grim quality, a man who could see a joke in the face of death and expected others to see it, too. "If the Black Dogs bother us, we'll salt their ears," he announced in a loud and hearty voice. "That's what you do in the stories, isn't it? Sprinkle salt on their ears, and they vanish." A few of the lancers laughed, though the miasma of fear did not lessen appreciably. Stories told by the fire were one thing, those same stories walking in the flesh quite another. Gallenne led his black to Berelain and rested a gauntleted hand on her bay's neck. He gave Perrin a considering look that Perrin returned levelly, refusing to take the hint.

wʌtɛvɝ ðə mæn hæd tə seɪ, hi kəd seɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən ɛɹæm. ɡælɛn saɪd. "ðeɪ wɪl kip ðɛɹ nɝv, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd sɔfli, "bʌt ðə fækt ɪz, əɹ pəzɪʃən ɪz pɹikɛɹiəs, wɪð ɛnəmiz ɑn ɛvɹi saɪɾ ən əɹ səplaɪz ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt. ʃæɾoʊzpɔn kən oʊnli meɪk mæɾɝz wɝs. maɪ duɾi ɪz tə jə ən min, maɪ leɪɾi, ən wɪð ɔl ɹɪspɛk tə lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, jə meɪ wɪʃ tə ɔltɝ jəɹ plænz." æŋɡɝ kɹækəld ɪn pɛɹɪn - ðə mæn wəɾ əbændən feɪl! - bʌt bɹəleɪn spoʊk bɪfɔɹ i kəd sədʒɛst ɪt.

Whatever the man had to say, he could say in front of him and Aram. Gallenne sighed. "They will keep their nerve, my Lady," he said softly, "but the fact is, our position is precarious, with enemies on every side and our supplies running out. Shadowspawn can only make matters worse. My duty is to you and Mayene, my Lady, and with all respect to Lord Perrin, you may wish to alter your plans." Anger crackled in Perrin - the man would abandon Faile! - but Berelain spoke before he could suggest it.

"ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ ɔltɝeɪʃən, lɔɹd ɡælɛn." səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz izi tə fɝɡɛt ðət ʃi wɑz ə ɹulɝ, smɔl ðoʊ min wɑz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹiɡəl noʊɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs fɪt fəɹ ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ. bæk stʃɹeɪt, ʃi meɪɾ əɹ sæɾəl sim ə θɹoʊn, ən ʃi spoʊk laʊdli ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛvɹiwʌn hɝɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən, fɝmli ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðə dɪsɪʒən hæd bɪn meɪd. "ɪf wɪv ɛnəmiz ɔl ɝaʊnd, ðən ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪz əz seɪf əz tɝnɪŋ bæk əɹ tɝnɪŋ əsaɪd. jɛɾ ɪf tɝnɪŋ bæk əɹ tɝnɪŋ əsaɪd wɝ tɛn taɪmz seɪfɝ, aɪ wəd stɪl ɡoʊ ɑn. aɪ ɪntɛn tə si ðə leɪɾi feɪl ɹɛskjuɾ ɪf wi mʌs faɪɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ə θaʊzən dɑɹkhaʊnz, ən tʃɹɑləks əz wɛl. ðəɾ aɪ hæv swɔɹn tə du!" ə ɹɔɹ ə tʃɪɹz ænsɝd hɝ, wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən θɹʌstɪŋ ðɛɹ lænsɪz ɪndə ði ɛɹ soʊ ðə ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz dænst. ðə smɛl ə fɪɹ ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌt ðeɪ saʊndəd ɹɛɾi tə kʌt ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ɛni nʌmbɝ ə tʃɹɑləks ɹæðɝ ðən əpɪɹ lɛs ɪn bɹəleɪnz aɪz. ɡælɛn kəmændəd ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ fɛl mɔɹ ðən fɑndnəs fəɹ ðɛɹ ɹulɝ, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən wɪð mɛn. meɪbi kəz ʌv ɪt, ɪn pɑɹt.

"There will be no alteration, Lord Gallenne." Sometimes it was easy to forget that she was a ruler, small though Mayene was, but there was a regal note in her voice fit for the Queen of Andor. Back straight, she made her saddle seem a throne, and she spoke loudly enough to make sure everyone heard her decision, firmly enough that everyone knew the decision had been made. "If we have enemies all around, then going on is as safe as turning back or turning aside. Yet if turning back or turning aside were ten times safer, I would still go on. I intend to see the Lady Faile rescued if we must fight our way through a thousand Darkhounds, and Trollocs as well. That I have sworn to do!" A roar of cheers answered her, Winged Guards shouting and thrusting their lances into the air so the red streamers danced. The smell of fear remained, but they sounded ready to cut their way through any number of Trollocs rather than appear less in Berelain's eyes. Gallenne commanded them, but they felt more than fondness for their ruler, despite her reputation with men. Maybe because of it, in part.

bɹəleɪn hæd kɛp tiɹ fɹəm swɑloʊɪŋ min baɪ pleɪɪŋ wʌn mæn u faʊn əɹ bjuɾəfəl əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, pɛɹɪn faʊn ɪt hɑɹd nɑt tə ɡeɪp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ʃi saʊndəɾ əz dɪtɝmən əz i wɑz!

Berelain had kept Tear from swallowing Mayene by playing one man who found her beautiful against another. For his part, Perrin found it hard not to gape in surprise. She sounded as determined as he was!

ʃi smɛld əz dɪtɝmənd! ɡælɛn baʊɾ ɪz ɡɹeɪ hɛɾ ɪn ənwɪlɪŋ æksɛptəns, ən bɹəleɪn ɡeɪv ə smɔl, sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əɹ ətɛnʃən tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪsaɪd ðə stoʊn slæb.

She smelled as determined! Gallenne bowed his gray head in unwilling acceptance, and Berelain gave a small, satisfied nod before turning her attention to the Aes Sedai beside the stone slab.

mɑsʊɝi hæd stɑpt weɪvɪŋ əɹ hænz əbaʊɾ ən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə fʊtpɹɪns, tæpɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɡɛnst əɹ lɪps θɔtfəli. ʃi wɑz ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪθaʊt biɪŋ bjuɾəfəl, ðoʊ səm ə ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪɡləsnəs, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪs ən ɛləɡəns ðət maɪɾ ɔlsoʊ hæv kʌm fɹəm biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt wɑz ɔfən dɪfəkəl tə tɛl ə sɪstɝ u hæd bɪn bɔɹn ɑn ə hɑɹdskɹæbəl fɑɹm fɹəm wʌn bɔɹn ɪn ə ɡɹæn pæləs. pɛɹɪn hæd sin əɹ ɹɛd-feɪst ən æŋɡɹi, wɔɹn daʊn ən ɑn ði ɛn ə hɝ tɛðɝ, jɛt dɪspaɪt hɑɹd tʃɹævəl ən laɪf ɪn ði il tɛns, hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ ən əɹ kloʊðɪŋ lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ə meɪɾ ətɛndɪŋ hɝ, tu. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn stændɪŋ ɪn ə laɪbɹɛɹi.

Masuri had stopped waving her hands about and was staring at the footprints, tapping a finger against her lips thoughtfully. She was a pretty woman without being beautiful, though some of that might have been Aes Sedai agelessness, with a grace and elegance that might also have come from being Aes Sedai. It was often difficult to tell a sister who had been born on a hardscrabble farm from one born in a grand palace. Perrin had seen her red-faced and angry, worn down and on the end of her tether, yet despite hard travel and life in the Aiel tents, her dark hair and her clothing looked as though she had a maid attending her, too. She might have been standing in a library.

"wʌɾ əv jə lɝnd, mɑsʊɝi?" bɹəleɪn æskt. "mɑsʊɝi, ɪf jə pliz? mɑsʊɝi?" ðə læs keɪm ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli, ən mɑsʊɝi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, əz ðoʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. pɑsəbli ʃi wɑz stɑɹɾəld; ɪn mɛni weɪz ʃi simd mɔɹ ə ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ ðən ðə bɹaʊn, mɔɹ ɪntɛn ɑn ækʃən ðən ɑn kɑntəmpleɪʃən, stʃɹeɪt tə ðə pɔɪn ən nɛvɝ veɪɡ, jɛt ʃi wɑz stɪl keɪpəbəl ə luzɪŋ hɝsɛlf kəmplitli ɪn wʌtɛvɝ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ ɪntʃɹəst. foʊldɪŋ əɹ hænz əɾ əɹ weɪst, ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt ɹæðɝ ðən spikɪŋ, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ən lʊkt ə kwɛstʃən ət ðə waɪz wʌnz. "ɡoʊ ɑn, ɡɝl," nəvɛɝɪn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli, plæntɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ɪn ə dʒæŋɡəl ə bɹeɪslɪts. ə fɹaʊn meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ mɔɹ əɹ juʒəwəl sɛlf, bʌt niðɝ ə ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz lʊkt ɛni mɔɹ əpɹuvɪŋ. θɹi fɹaʊnz ɪn ə ɹoʊ laɪk θɹi peɪl-aɪd kɹoʊz ɑn ə fɛns. "wi wɝ nɑt sɪmpli lɛɾɪŋ jə ɛksɝsaɪz jəɹ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt. tɛl əs wʌt jə lɝnd." mɑsʊɝiz feɪs ɹɛɾənd, bʌt ʃi spoʊk ʌp ɪmiɾiətli, hɝ aɪz ɑn bɹəleɪn. ʃi kəd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ kɔl daʊn ɪn pʌblɪk, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɛniwʌn nu ʌv əɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz.

"What have you learned, Masuri?" Berelain asked. "Masuri, if you please? Masuri?" The last came a little more sharply, and Masuri gave a start, as though surprised to realize she was not alone. Possibly she was startled; in many ways she seemed more of the Green Ajah than the Brown, more intent on action than on contemplation, straight to the point and never vague, yet she was still capable of losing herself completely in whatever captured her interest. Folding her hands at her waist, she opened her mouth, but rather than speaking, she hesitated and looked a question at the Wise Ones. "Go on, girl," Nevarin said impatiently, planting her fists on her hips in a jangle of bracelets. A frown made her appear more her usual self, but neither of the other Wise Ones looked any more approving. Three frowns in a row like three pale-eyed crows on a fence. "We were not simply letting you exercise your curiosity. Get on with it. Tell us what you learned." Masuri's face reddened, but she spoke up immediately, her eyes on Berelain. She could not like being called down in public, no matter what anyone knew of her relationship with the Wise Ones.

"ɹɛləɾɪvli lɪɾəl ɪz noʊn ə dɑɹkhaʊnz, bʌɾ aɪv meɪd sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə stʌɾi ʌv ðɛm, ɪn ə smɔl weɪ. oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz, aɪ hæv kɹɔs ðə pæðz ə sɛvən pæks, faɪv ə ðɛm twaɪs ən tu ʌðɝz θɹi taɪmz." ðə kʌlɝ bɪɡæn tə feɪd fɹəm əɹ tʃiks, ən sloʊli ʃi bɪɡæn tə saʊn əz ɪf ʃi wɝ lɛktʃɝɪŋ. "sʌm eɪntʃən ɹaɪɾɝz seɪ ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊnli sɛvən pæks, ʌðɝz seɪ naɪn, əɹ θɝtin, əɹ səm ʌðɝ nʌmbɝ ðeɪ bɪliv hæd spɛʃəl səɡnɪfɪkəns, bʌt dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, sɔɹɛlænə ælsəən ɹoʊɾ ʌv 'ðə hʌnʒɹəd pæks ðə ʃædoʊz haʊnz ðət hʌn ðə naɪt,' ən ivən ɝliɝ, aɪvoʊneɪl bɹætiiə səpoʊzədli ɹoʊɾ ʌv 'haʊnz bɔɹn ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪn nʌmbɝz laɪk ʌntu ðə naɪtmɛɹz ə mænkaɪnd.' ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪvoʊneɪl hɝsɛlf meɪ bi əpɑkɹəfəl. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə - " ʃi dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ɪf ɡɹoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ə wɝd. "smɛl ɪz nɑt ðə ɹaɪt wɝd, ən niðɝ ɪz fleɪvɝ. ðə sɛns ʌv itʃ pæk ɪz junik, ən aɪ kən seɪ wɪð sɝɾənti ðəɾ aɪ hæv nɛvɝ ɪnkaʊntɝd ðɪs wʌn bɪfɔɹ, soʊ wi noʊ ðə nʌmbɝ sɛvən ɪz ɹɔŋ. wɛðɝ ðə kɝɛk nʌmbɝ ɪz naɪn əɹ θɝtin əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, teɪlz ə dɑɹkhaʊnz ɑɹ mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmən ðən dɑɹkhaʊnz ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛɹ ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ ə ðə blaɪt. ə sɛkən ɹɛɹəɾi: ðəɹ meɪ hæv bɪn əz mɛni əz fɪfti ɪn ðɪs pæk. tɛn əɹ twɛlv ɪz ðə juʒəwəl lɪmət. ə jusfəl mæksəm: tu ɹɛɹɪɾiz kəmbaɪn kɔl fəɹ kloʊs ətɛnʃən." pɔzɪŋ, ʃi ɹeɪzd ə fɪŋɡɝ tə ɛmfəsaɪz ðə pɔɪnt, ðən nɑɾəd wən ʃi θɔt bɹəleɪn hæd teɪkən ɪt, ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz əɡɛn. ə ɡʌstɪŋ bɹiz pʊʃt əɹ jɛloʊɪʃ-bɹaʊn kloʊk ɔf wʌn ʃoʊldɝ, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə noʊɾəs ðə lɔs ʌv wɔɹmθ. "ðɛɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə fil ə ɝdʒənsi əbaʊt dɑɹkhaʊnz' tʃɹeɪlz, bʌɾ ɪt vɛɹiz əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ə nʌmbɝ ə fæktɝz, nɑɾ ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ aɪ kən bi sɝɾən ʌv. ðɪs wʌn əz ən ɪntɛns ædmɪkstʃɝ ʌv. . . aɪ səpoʊz jə kəd kɔl ɪɾ ɪmpeɪʃəns. ðəɾ ɪzən ɹɪli stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf, baɪ fɑɹ - əz wɛl kɔl ə stæbwaʊn ə pɪnpɹɪk - bʌɾ ɪɾəl du. aɪ wəd seɪ ðɛɹ hʌn əz bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn fəɹ səm taɪm, ən ðɛɹ pɹeɪ ɪz ɪluɾɪŋ əm sʌmhaʊ. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə stɔɹiz seɪ - baɪ ðə weɪ, lɔɹd ɡælɛn, sɔl dʌzn hɑɹm dɑɹkhaʊnz ɪn ðə list." soʊ ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɪntaɪɝli lɔst ɪn θɔɾ æftɝ ɔl. "dɪspaɪt ðə stɔɹiz, ðeɪ nɛvɝ hʌn ət ɹændəm, ðoʊ ðəl kɪl ɪf ði ɑpɝtunəɾi pɹizɛns ɪtsɛlf ən dʌzn ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð ðə hʌnt. wɪð dɑɹkhaʊnz, ðə hʌn ɪz pɛɹəmaʊnt. ðɛɹ kwɔɹi ɪz ɔlweɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðoʊ ət taɪmz wi kænɑt si waɪ. ðeɪv bɪn noʊn tə baɪpæs ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ən maɪɾi tə sleɪ ə fɑɹmwaɪf əɹ ə kɹæfsmən, əɹ tə ɛntɝ ə taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ ən liv wɪθaʊt kɪlɪŋ, ðoʊ klɪɹli ðeɪ keɪm fəɹ səm ɹizən. maɪ fɝs θɔt fəɹ wʌt bɹɔɾ əm hɪɹ hæd tə bi dɪskɑɹɾɪd, sɪns ðeɪ muvd ɑn." hɝ ɡeɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn, soʊ kwɪkli hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls noʊɾəst. "ɡɪvən ðæt, aɪ stʃɹɔŋli daʊt ðəl ɹɪtɝn.

"Relatively little is known of Darkhounds, but I've made something of a study of them, in a small way. Over the years, I have crossed the paths of seven packs, five of them twice and two others three times." The color began to fade from her cheeks, and slowly she began to sound as if she were lecturing. "Some ancient writers say there are only seven packs, others say nine, or thirteen, or some other number they believed had special significance, but during the Trolloc Wars, Sorelana Alsahhan wrote of 'the hundred packs the Shadow's hounds that hunt the night,' and even earlier, Ivonell Bharatiya supposedly wrote of 'hounds born of the Shadow, in numbers like unto the nightmares of mankind.' Though in truth, Ivonell herself may be apocryphal. In any case, the - " She gestured as if groping for a word. "Smell is not the right word, and neither is flavor. The sense of each pack is unique, and I can say with certainty that I have never encountered this one before, so we know the number seven is wrong. Whether the correct number is nine or thirteen or something else, tales of Darkhounds are much more common than Darkhounds themselves, and they are extremely rare this far south of the Blight. A second rarity: there may have been as many as fifty in this pack. Ten or twelve is the usual limit. A useful maxim: two rarities combined call for close attention." Pausing, she raised a finger to emphasize the point, then nodded when she thought Berelain had taken it, and folded her hands again. A gusting breeze pushed her yellowish-brown cloak off one shoulder, yet she did not appear to notice the loss of warmth. "There is always a feel of urgency about Darkhounds' trails, but it varies according to a number of factors, not all of which I can be certain of. This one has an intense admixture of. . . I suppose you could call it impatience. That isn't really strong enough, by far - as well call a stabwound a pinprick - but it will do. I would say their hunt has been going on for some time, and their prey is eluding them somehow. No matter what the stories say - by the way, Lord Gallenne, salt doesn't harm Darkhounds in the least." So she had not been entirely lost in thought after all. "Despite the stories, they never hunt at random, though they will kill if the opportunity presents itself and doesn't interfere with the hunt. With Darkhounds, the hunt is paramount. Their quarry is always important to the Shadow, though at times we cannot see why. They have been known to bypass the great and mighty to slay a farmwife or a craftsman, or to enter a town or village and leave without killing, though clearly they came for some reason. My first thought for what brought them here had to be discarded, since they moved on." Her gaze flickered toward Perrin, so quickly he was not sure anyone else noticed. "Given that, I strongly doubt they will return.

oʊ, jɛs; ən ðeɪ ɑɹ ən aʊɝ əɹ mɔɹ ɡɔn. ðæt, aɪm əfɹeɪd, ɪz ɹɪli ɔl aɪ kən tɛl ju." nəvɛɝɪn ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz nɑɾəd ðɛɹ əpɹuvəl əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt, ən ə tʌtʃ ə kʌlɝ ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ tʃiks, ðoʊ ɪt vænɪʃt kwɪkli əz ʃi əsumd ə mæsk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi. ə ʃɪft ɪn ðə bɹiz bɹɔɾ əɹ sɛn tə pɛɹɪn, sɝpɹaɪzd ən plizd, ən əpsɛɾ ət biɪŋ plizd. "θæŋk ju, mɑsʊɝi sədaɪ," bɹəleɪn sɛd fɔɹməli, meɪkɪŋ ə smɔl baʊ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl ðət mɑsʊɝi æknɑlɪdʒd wɪð ə slaɪt moʊʃən ə hɝ hɛd. "ju hæv pʊɾ əɹ maɪnz ət ɹɛst." ɪndid, ðə fɪɹ smɛl əmʌŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz bɪɡæn tə feɪd, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hɝd ɡælɛn ɡɹʌmbəl ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, "ʃi maɪɾ əv toʊl ðoʊz læs bɪts fɝst."

Oh, yes; and they are an hour or more gone. That, I'm afraid, is really all I can tell you." Nevarin and the other Wise Ones nodded their approval as she finished, and a touch of color returned to her cheeks, though it vanished quickly as she assumed a mask of Aes Sedai serenity. A shift in the breeze brought her scent to Perrin, surprised and pleased, and upset at being pleased. "Thank you, Masuri Sedai," Berelain said formally, making a small bow in her saddle that Masuri acknowledged with a slight motion of her head. "You have put our minds at rest." Indeed, the fear smell among the soldiers began to fade, though Perrin heard Gallenne grumble under his breath, "She might have told those last bits first."

pɛɹɪnz ɪɹz kɑt sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, tu, θɹu ðə stæmpɪŋ ə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz ən mɛnz kwaɪət, ɹɪliv læftɝ. ə bluəɾɪts tʃɹɪl saʊndəd tə ðə saʊθ, bɪɑn ðə hɪɹɪŋ ʌv ɛniwʌn ɛls ðɛɹ, fɑloʊd kloʊsli baɪ ðə bʌzɪŋ kɔl ʌv ə mæsk spɛɹoʊ. ənʌðɝ bluəɾɪt saʊndəd, kloʊsɝ, fɑloʊɾ əɡɛn baɪ ə mæsk spɛɹoʊ, ən ðən ðə seɪm pɛɹ kɔld əɡɛn kloʊsɝ stɪl. ðəɹ maɪt bi bluəɾəts ən mæsk spɛɹoʊz ɪn ɔltɑɹə, bʌɾ i nu ðiz bɝdz kæɹid tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊz. ðə bluəɾɪt mɛn mɛn wɝ kʌmɪŋ, mɔɹ ðən ə fju ən meɪbi ənfɹɛnli. ðə mæsk spɛɹoʊ, ðət səm bæk hoʊm kɔl ðə θifbɝd fəɹ ɪts hæbəɾ ə stilɪŋ bɹaɪɾ ɑbʒɛkts, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd. . . . pɛɹɪn ɹæn ə θʌm əlɔŋ ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz æks, bʌɾ i weɪɾəd fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ pɛɹ ə kɔlz, kloʊs ɪnʌf ðət ði ʌðɝz maɪɾ əv noʊɾəst.

Perrin's ears caught something else, too, through the stamping of horses' hooves and men's quiet, relieved laughter. A bluetit's trill sounded to the south, beyond the hearing of anyone else there, followed closely by the buzzing call of a masked sparrow. Another bluetit sounded, closer, followed again by a masked sparrow, and then the same pair called again closer still. There might be bluetits and masked sparrows in Altara, but he knew these birds carried Two Rivers longbows. The bluetit meant men were coming, more than a few and maybe unfriendly. The masked sparrow, that some back home called the thiefbird for its habit of stealing bright objects, on the other hand. . . . Perrin ran a thumb along the edge of his axe, but he waited for one more pair of calls, close enough that the others might have noticed.

"dɪd jə hɪɹ ðæt?" hi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ saʊθ əz ɪf i hæd dʒʌs hɝd. "maɪ sɛntʃɹiz əv spɑɾəd mæsimə." ðət bɹɔt hɛdz ʌp, lɪsnɪŋ, ən sɛvɹəl mɛn nɑɾəd wən ðə kɔlz wɝ ɹɪpiɾɪd, kloʊsɝ stɪl. "hiz kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ."

"Did you hear that?" he said, looking south as if he had just heard. "My sentries have spotted Masema." That brought heads up, listening, and several men nodded when the calls were repeated, closer still. "He's coming this way."

ɡɹoʊlɪŋ kɝsɪz, ɡælɛn klæpt ɪz hɛlməɾ ɑntu hɪz hɛɾ ən maʊntəd. ənʊɹə ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz, ən mɑsʊɝi bɪɡæn flaʊndɝɪŋ bæk təwɔɹɾ əɹ dæpəl. ðə lænsɝz ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən bɪɡæn ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf smɛlz ʌv æŋɡɝ, wʌns mɔɹ tʌtʃt wɪð fɪɹ. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz wɝ oʊɾ ə blʌd dɛt baɪ mæsimə, ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, bʌt nʌn wɑz æŋkʃəs tə tʃɹaɪ kəlɛktɪŋ wɪð oʊnli fɪfti mɛn, nɑt wən mæsimə ɔlweɪz ɹoʊd wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd əɾ ɪz bæk.

Growling curses, Gallenne clapped his helmet onto his head and mounted. Annoura gathered her reins, and Masuri began floundering back toward her dapple. The lancers shifted in their saddles and began giving off smells of anger, once more touched with fear. The Winged Guards were owed a blood debt by Masema, in their eyes, but none was anxious to try collecting with only fifty men, not when Masema always rode with a hundred at his back.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt ɹʌn fɹəm hɪm," bɹəleɪn ənaʊnst. ʃi stɛɹd saʊθ wɛɹɪŋ ə koʊl fɹaʊn. "wi wɪl weɪt fəɹ ɪm hɪɹ."

"I will not run from him," Berelain announced. She stared south wearing a cold frown. "We will wait for him here."

ɡælɛn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ - tə hɝ, ət list. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi bɪɡæn tə bɛloʊ ɔɹɾɝz ɝeɪɪŋ ɪz ɡɑɹdzmɪn. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ən izi mæɾɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɑɹ əpɑɹt ðə tʃɹiz stʊd, fɔɹəsts wɝ pʊɹ pleɪsəz fəɹ lænsɝz. ɛni tʃɑɹdʒ wəd bi dɪsdʒɔɪntɪɾ əɾ ɪts stɑɹt, ən stɪkɪŋ ə mæn wɪð ə læns wɑz dɪfəkəlt wən i kəd dɑdʒ bɪhaɪn ə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk ən kʌm aʊt bɪhaɪn ju. ɡælɛn tʃɹaɪd tə fɔɹm əm ɪn fɹʌn ə bɹəleɪn, bɪtwin əɹ ən ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ mɛn, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk, ən ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn tʃeɪnʒd ɪz kəmænz, laɪnɪŋ ðə lænsɝz ʌp ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl kɹʊkəd ɹæŋk, bʌlʒɪŋ ɝaʊn mæsɪv tʃɹiz bʌt sɛntɝɾ ɑn hɝ. wʌn soʊlʒɝ ɡælɛn sɛn ɹeɪsɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ loʊ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl wɪð ɪz læns loʊ əz ɪf ət ðə tʃɑɹdʒ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əz fæst əz i kəɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə snoʊ ən tɝeɪn. bɹəleɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðæt, jɛt sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Gallenne opened his mouth, and closed it again without speaking - to her, at least. Drawing a deep breath, he began to bellow orders arraying his Guardsmen. That was not an easy matter. No matter how far apart the trees stood, forests were poor places for lancers. Any charge would be disjointed at its start, and sticking a man with a lance was difficult when he could dodge behind a tree trunk and come out behind you. Gallenne tried to form them in front of Berelain, between her and the approaching men, but she gave him a sharp look, and the one-eyed man changed his commands, lining the lancers up in a single crooked rank, bulging around massive trees but centered on her. One soldier Gallenne sent racing back toward the camp, crouching low in his saddle with his lance low as if at the charge, riding as fast as he could in spite of the snow and terrain. Berelain raised an eyebrow at that, yet said nothing.

ənʊɹə bɪɡæn ɡaɪɾɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊn mɛɹ təwɔɹd bɹəleɪn, bʌt stɑpt wən mɑsʊɝi kɔld əɹ neɪm. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ hæd ɡæðɝɾ əɹ dæpəl bʌt stɪl stʊɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz ɝaʊn hɝ, hu wɝ tɔl ɪnʌf ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən tə meɪk əɹ sim lɛs ðən fʊl-ɡɹoʊn. ənʊɹə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əntɪl mɑsʊɝi sʌmən əɹ əɡɛn, mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli, ən ðən pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i hɝɾ ənʊɹə saɪ hɛvəli bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹoʊd tə ðɛm ən dɪsmaʊntɪd. wʌtɛvɝ ði il wɪmən hæd tə seɪ, ɪn vɔɪsəz pɪtʃt tu sɔfli fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə hɪɹ, klʌstɝɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ənʊɹə wɪð hɛdz bɛn kloʊs tə hɝz, ðə tæɹɑbənɝ sɪstɝ dɪd nɑt laɪk. hɝ feɪs ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən ɪn əɹ hʊd, bʌɾ əɹ θɪn bɹeɪdz swʌŋ ɛvɝ fæstɝ wɪð ðə ʃeɪkɪŋ ə hɝ hɛd, ən ət læst ʃi tɝn əweɪ əbɹʌpli ən pʊɾ ə fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp ə hɝ sæɾəl.

Annoura began guiding her brown mare toward Berelain, but stopped when Masuri called her name. The Brown sister had gathered her dapple but still stood in the snow with the Wise Ones around her, who were tall enough in comparison to make her seem less than full-grown. Annoura hesitated until Masuri summoned her again, more sharply, and then Perrin thought he heard Annoura sigh heavily before she rode to them and dismounted. Whatever the Aiel women had to say, in voices pitched too softly for Perrin to hear, clustering in front of Annoura with heads bent close to hers, the Taraboner sister did not like. Her face remained hidden in her hood, but her thin braids swung ever faster with the shaking of her head, and at last she turned away abruptly and put a foot in the stirrup of her saddle.

mɑsʊɝi hæd bɪn stændɪŋ kwaɪətli, lɛɾɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz əv ðɛɹ seɪ, bʌt naʊ ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ənʊɹəz sliv ən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs ðət meɪɾ ənʊɹəz ʃoʊldɝz slʌmp ən ðə waɪz wʌnz nɑd. pʊʃɪŋ bæk əɹ hʊd tə fɔl daʊn əɹ bæk, ənʊɹə weɪɾəd fəɹ mɑsʊɝi tə klaɪm ɑntu hɝ mɛɹ bɪfɔɹ maʊntɪŋ əɹ oʊn hɔɹs, ən ðən ðə tu sɪstɝz ɹoʊd bæk tə ðə laɪn ə lænsɝz təɡɛðɝ, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪn bɪsaɪd bɹəleɪn wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz pʊʃɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin ðɛm, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd fɹəm pɛɹɪn.

Masuri had been standing quietly, letting the Wise Ones have their say, but now she laid a hand on Annoura's sleeve and said something in a low voice that made Annoura's shoulders slump and the Wise Ones nod. Pushing back her hood to fall down her back, Annoura waited for Masuri to climb onto her mare before mounting her own horse, and then the two sisters rode back to the line of lancers together, crowding in beside Berelain with the Wise Ones pushing in between them, on the other side from Perrin.

ənʊɹəz waɪd maʊθ wɑz tɝn daʊn ɪn ə ɡlʌm kɝv, ən ʃi wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ θʌmz nɝvəsli.

Annoura's wide mouth was turned down in a glum curve, and she was rubbing her thumbs nervously.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt jəɹ plænɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn æskt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə haɪd səspɪʃəs. meɪbi ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd lɛt mɑsʊɝi mit wɪð mæsimə, jɛt ðeɪ stɪl kleɪm tə θɪŋk ðə mæn wɑz bɛɾɝ dɛd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ, bʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd noʊ sətʃ pɹoʊəbɪʃən. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ lɪŋkt. hi nu mɔɹ ðən i wɑntəɾ əbaʊt ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən ɪnʌf əbaʊt ðə waɪz wʌnz tə bi ʃʊɹ ðət nəvɛɝɪn wəd bi ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ɪf ðeɪ hæd fɔɹmd ə sɝkəl. ənʊɹə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt snæpt ɪt ʃʌɾ əɾ ə wɔɹnɪŋ tʌtʃ fɹəm kɛɹɛl ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət mɑsʊɝi. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ pɝst əɹ lɪps ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt sim tə mɑləfaɪ ənʊɹə. hɝ ɡlʌv hænz ɡɹɪpt əɹ ɹeɪnz soʊ taɪtli ðət ðeɪ ʃʊk.

"What is it you're planning?" Perrin asked, trying not to hide suspicious. Maybe the Wise Ones had let Masuri meet with Masema, yet they still claimed to think the man was better dead. The Aes Sedai could not use the Power as a weapon unless they were in danger, but the Wise Ones had no such prohibition. He wondered whether they were linked. He knew more than he wanted about the One Power, and enough about the Wise Ones to be sure that Nevarin would be in control if they had formed a circle. Annoura opened her mouth, but snapped it shut at a warning touch from Carelle and glared at Masuri. The Brown sister pursed her lips and shook her head slightly, which did not seem to mollify Annoura. Her gloved hands gripped her reins so tightly that they shook.

nəvɛɝɪn lʊkt ʌp ət pɛɹɪn pæs bɹəleɪn əz ɪf ʃi ɹɛɾ ɪz maɪnd. "tɪldəwi plæn tə si jə seɪfli bæk tə ðə kæmp, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli, "ju ən bɹəleɪn pɹən. wi plæn tə si ðəɾ əz mɛni əz pɑsəbəl sɝvaɪv ðɪs deɪ, ən ðə deɪz tə kʌm. juv əbdʒɛkʃənz?"

Nevarin looked up at Perrin past Berelain as if she read his mind. "~We plan to see you safely back to the camp, Perrin Aybara," she said sharply, "you and Berelain Paeron. We plan to see that as many as possible survive this day, and the days to come. Do you have objections?"

"dʒʌs doʊn də ɛniθɪŋ ənlɛs aɪ tɛl ju," hi sɛd. ən ænsɝ laɪk ðət kəd min ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz.

"Just don't do anything unless I tell you," he said. An answer like that could mean a lot of things.

"nɑɾ ɛniθɪŋ." nəvɛɝɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst, ən kɛɹɛl læft əz ɪf i hæd meɪɾ ə hjudʒ dʒoʊk.

"Not anything." Nevarin shook her head in disgust, and Carelle laughed as if he had made a huge joke.

nʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz sim tə θɪŋk ɛni mɔɹ ɹɪspɑns wɑz niɾəd. ðeɪ hæd bɪn kəmændəd tə oʊbeɪ hɪm, bʌt ðɛɹ noʊʃənz ʌv oʊbiɾiəns feɪl tə skwɛɹ wɪð ɛni hi hæɾ ɛvɝ lɝnd. pɪɡz wəd ɡɹoʊ wɪŋz bɪfɔɹ i ɡɑɾ ə bɛɾɝ ænsɝ aʊɾ ə ðɛm.

None of the Wise Ones seemed to think any more response was needed. They had been commanded to obey him, but their notions of obedience failed to square with any he had ever learned. Pigs would grow wings before he got a better answer out of them.

hi cʊɾə pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ɪt. hi nu hi ʃʊd. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd plænd, miɾɪŋ mæsimə ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə kæmp, wən ðə mæn hæd tə noʊ hu hæd stoʊlən ɪz sintʃæn peɪpɝ, wɑz laɪk hoʊpɪŋ tə snætʃ jəɹ hæn ɔf ði ænvəl bɪfɔɹ ðə hæmɝ fɛl. bɹəleɪn wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ əz ðə waɪz wʌnz wən ɪt keɪm tə fɑloʊɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, bʌɾ i θɔt ʃi wəd lɪsən ɪf i ɡeɪv ən ɔɹɾɝ tə wɪðdʒɹɔ tə ðə kæmp. hi θɔt ʃi wʊd, fəɹ ɔl ðəɾ əɹ smɛl sɛd ʃi hæɾ əɹ hilz dʌɡ ɪn hɑɹd. steɪɪŋ wɑz ə sɛnsləs ɹɪsk. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i kəd kənvɪns əɹ ə ðæt. jɛɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹʌn fɹəm ðə mæn, iðɝ. pɑɹɾ ə hɪm sɛɾ i wɑz biɪŋ ə ful. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹt smoʊldɝd wɪð æŋɡɝ ðəɾ i faʊn hɑɹd tə kəntʃɹoʊl. ɛɹæm kɹaʊɾəd ɪn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm skaʊlɪŋ, bʌɾ ət list i hæd nɑt dʒɹɔn ɪz sɔɹd. weɪvɪŋ ə sɔɹd maɪt pʊɾ ə hɑt koʊl ɪn ðə heɪlɔft, ən ðə taɪm fəɹ ə kɑnfɹənteɪʃən wɪð mæsimə hæd nɑt kʌm jɛt. pɛɹɪn ɹɛstəɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz æks. nɑt jɛt.

He could have put a stop to it. He knew he should. No matter what the Wise Ones had planned, meeting Masema this far from the others in the camp, when the man had to know who had stolen his Seanchan paper, was like hoping to snatch your hand off the anvil before the hammer fell. Berelain was almost as bad as the Wise Ones when it came to following orders, but he thought she would listen if he gave an order to withdraw to the camp. He thought she would, for all that her smell said she had her heels dug in hard. Staying was a senseless risk. He was sure he could convince her of that. Yet he did not want to run from the man, either. Part of him said he was being a fool. The larger part smoldered with anger that he found hard to control. Aram crowded in beside him scowling, but at least he had not drawn his sword. Waving a sword might put a hot coal in the hayloft, and the time for a confrontation with Masema had not come yet. Perrin rested a hand on his axe. Not yet.

dɪspaɪt ðə ʃɑɹpli æŋɡəld ɹeɪz ə laɪt ðət pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd θɹu ðə θɪk bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd, ðə fɔɹəst əz ə hoʊl leɪ ɹæpt ɪn dɪm ɝli-mɔɹnɪŋ ʃædoʊz. ivən ət nun, ɪt wəd bi dɪm hɪɹ.

Despite the sharply angled rays of light that penetrated through the thick branches overhead, the forest as a whole lay wrapped in dim early-morning shadows. Even at noon, it would be dim here.

saʊnz keɪm tə hɪm fɝst, ðə mʌfəl θʌɾ ə hʊvz ɪn snoʊ, ðə hɛvi bɹɛθ ə hɔɹsəz pʊʃt fəɹ spid, ən ðən ə mæs ə ɹaɪɾɝz əpɪɹd, ə dɪsɔɹɾɝd mɑb floʊɪŋ nɔɹθ əmʌŋ ðə hjudʒ tʃɹiz əɾ ə nɪɹ-ɡæləp ɪn spaɪɾ ə snoʊ ən ɹʌf ɡɹaʊnd. ɹæðɝ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd, ðeɪ nʌmbɝd tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz ðæt. ə hɔɹs wɛn daʊn wɪð ə skɹim ən leɪɪŋ θɹæʃɪŋ ətɑp ɪts ɹaɪɾɝ, bʌt nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz soʊ mʌtʃ əz sloʊɾ əntɪl, səm sɛvənti əɹ eɪɾi peɪsɪz əweɪ, ðə mæn ət ðɛɹ hɛd ɹeɪzd ə hænd, ən ðeɪ sʌɾənli dʒɹu ɹeɪn ɪn spɹeɪz ə snoʊ, læðɝd hɔɹsəz bloʊɪŋ hɑɹɾ ən stimɪŋ. hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, lænsɪz stʌk ʌp əmʌŋ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz. moʊst wɔɹ noʊ ɑɹmɝ, ən mɛni dʒʌst ə bɹɛstpleɪɾ əɹ ə hɛlmət, jɛt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz wɝ hʌŋ əbaʊt wɪð sɔɹdz ən æksiz ən meɪsəz. ʃæfs ə sʌnlaɪt pɪkt aʊɾ ə fju feɪsəz, ɡɹɪm flæt-aɪd mɛn u lʊkt əz ðoʊ ðeɪ nɛvɝ hæd smaɪld ən nɛvɝ wʊd. ɪɾ əkɝd tə pɛɹɪn ðəɾ i maɪɾ əv meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk nɑt tə oʊvɝɹul bɹəleɪn. ðət wɑz wʌt keɪm ə heɪsti dɪsɪʒənz, ʌv lɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɝ də hɪz θɪŋkɪŋ. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət ʃi ɔfən ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋz, ən mæsimə maɪt bi dɛspɹɪt tə ɹɪkʌvɝ ɪz sintʃæn dɑkjəmɛnt. ivən wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz, ə faɪɾ ɪn ðiz wʊdz kəd tɝn blʌɾi, ə fɹi-fɔɹ-ɔl wɛɹ mɛn, ən wɪmən, kəd daɪ wɪθaʊt wʌns siɪŋ u kɪl ðɛm. ɪf noʊ wɪtnəsəz lɪvd, ɪt kəɾ ɔlweɪz bi bleɪmd ɑn bændəts əɹ ivən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðət hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ. ən ɪf ðəɹ wɝ wɪtnəsəz lɛft, mæsimə wɑz nɑɾ əbʌv hæŋɪŋ ə fju dʌzən ə hɪz oʊn mɛn ən kleɪmɪŋ ðə ɡɪlti hæd bɪn pʌnɪʃt. hi laɪkli wɑntəd tə kip pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə əlaɪv fəɹ ə waɪl jɛt, ðoʊ, ən i wəd nɑɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd ðə waɪz wʌnz, əɹ ə sɛkən ɛɛs sədaɪ. smɔl pɔɪns tə hæŋ fɪfti-ɑd lɪvz ɑn. vɛɹi smɔl pɔɪns tə hæŋ feɪlz laɪf ɑn. pɛɹɪn izd ɪz æks ɪn ɪts lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt. bɪsaɪd hɪm, bɹəleɪn smɛld ə kul kɑm ən stoʊni dɪtɝməneɪʃən. noʊ fɪɹ, ɑdli. nɑɾ ə wɪf. ɛɹæm smɛld . . . ɪksaɪɾəd.

Sounds came to him first, the muffled thud of hooves in snow, the heavy breath of horses pushed for speed, and then a mass of riders appeared, a disordered mob flowing north among the huge trees at a near-gallop in spite of snow and rough ground. Rather than a hundred, they numbered two or three times that. A horse went down with a scream and laying thrashing atop its rider, but none of the others so much as slowed until, some seventy or eighty paces away, the man at their head raised a hand, and they suddenly drew rein in sprays of snow, lathered horses blowing hard and steaming. Here and there, lances stuck up among the riders. Most wore no armor, and many just a breastplate or a helmet, yet their saddles were hung about with swords and axes and maces. Shafts of sunlight picked out a few faces, grim flat-eyed men who looked as though they never had smiled and never would. It occurred to Perrin that he might have made a mistake not to overrule Berelain. That was what came of hasty decisions, of letting anger do his thinking. Everyone knew that she often rode out in the mornings, and Masema might be desperate to recover his Seanchan document. Even with the Aes Sedai and Wise Ones, a fight in these woods could turn bloody, a free-for-all where men, and women, could die without once seeing who killed them. If no witnesses lived, it could always be blamed on bandits or even the Shaido. That had happened before. And if there were witnesses left, Masema was not above hanging a few dozen of his own men and claiming the guilty had been punished. He likely wanted to keep Perrin Aybara alive for a while yet, though, and he would not have expected the Wise Ones, or a second Aes Sedai. Small points to hang fifty-odd lives on. Very small points to hang Faile's life on. Perrin eased his axe in its loop on his belt. Beside him, Berelain smelled of cool calm and stony determination. No fear, oddly. Not a whiff. Aram smelled . . . excited.

ðə tu pɑɹɾiz sæt ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn saɪləns, əntɪl ət læs mæsimə ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd, fɑloʊd baɪ dʒʌs tu mɛn, ɔl θɹi pʊʃɪŋ bæk ðɛɹ hʊdz. nʌn wɔɹ ə hɛlmət, əɹ ɛni pis ʌv ɑɹmɝ. laɪk mæsimə, nɛŋɡɝ ən bɑɹɾu wɝ ʃaɪnɝən, bʌt laɪk hɪm, ðeɪ hæd ʃeɪvd ɔf ðɛɹ tɑpnɑts, livɪŋ bɛɹ hɛdz wɪð ə lʊk ə skʌlz. ðə kʌmɪŋ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd bɹoʊkən ɔl bɑnz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðoʊz ðət hæd plɛdʒ ðiz mɛn tə faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt. nɛŋɡɝ ən bɑɹɾu itʃ kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk ən hæɾ ənʌðɝ hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪz sæɾəlboʊ, ən bɑɹɾu, ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ tu, hæɾ ə keɪs hɔɹsboʊ ən ə kwɪvɝ fæsən tə hɪz sæɾəl, tu. mæsimə wɔɹ noʊ vɪzəbəl wɛpənz. ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn niɾəd nʌn. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡlæd tə si ɡælɛn wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɛn mæsimə hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd, fəɹ ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt mæsimə ðət dʒɹu ði aɪ. meɪbi ɪt wɑz oʊnli noʊɪŋ u hi wɑz, bʌt ðət wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf. mæsimə stɑpt ɪz ɹeɪnʒi sɔɹəl ə fju peɪsɪz fɹəm pɛɹɪn. ðə pɹɑfət wɑz ə dɑɹk fɹaʊnɪŋ mæn ʌv ævɝɪdʒ saɪz wɪð ə feɪɾəd æɹoʊ-skɑɹ waɪɾ ɑn ɪz tʃik, ɪn ə wɔɹn bɹaʊn wʊlən koʊɾ ən ə dɑɹk kloʊk wɪð fɹeɪɾ ɛdʒəz. mæsimə kɛɹd nʌθɪŋ fəɹ əpɪɹənsəz, list ʌv ɔl ɪz oʊn. əɾ ɪz bæk, nɛŋɡɝ ən bɑɹɾu hɛld ə fivɝ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, bʌt mæsiməz dip-sɛt, ɔlmoʊs blæk aɪz simd əz hɑɾ əz koʊlz ɪn ə fɔɹdʒ, əz ðoʊ ðə bɹizɪz mʌst sun fæn əm tə ə ɡloʊ, ən ɪz smɛl wɑz ðə dʒæŋɡəld, dɑɹɾɪŋ ʃɑɹpnəs ə pjʊɹ ɪnsænəɾi. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ə skɔɹn i dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə haɪd. waɪz wʌnz wɝ wɝs ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪn ɪz vju; ðeɪ nɑɾ oʊnli blæsfim baɪ tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ðeɪ wɝ il sævədʒəz tə but, ə dʌbəl sɪn. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz cʊɾə bɪn dʒʌs mɔɹ ʃædoʊz bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz. "ju ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ ə pɪknɪk?" hi sɛd wɪð ə ɡlæns ət ðə bæskət hæŋɪŋ fɹəm pɛɹɪnz sæɾəl. nɔɹməli, mæsiməz vɔɪs wɑz əz ɪntɛns əz ɪz aɪz, bʌt naʊ ɪt saʊndəd ɹaɪ, ən ɪz lɪp kɝld əz ɪz aɪz tʃɹævəl tə bɹəleɪn. hi hæd hɝd ðə ɹumɝz, ʌv kɔɹs.

The two parties sat regarding one another in silence, until at last Masema rode forward, followed by just two men, all three pushing back their hoods. None wore a helmet, or any piece of armor. Like Masema, Nengar and Bartu were Shienaran, but like him, they had shaved off their topknots, leaving bare heads with a look of skulls. The coming of the Dragon Reborn had broken all bonds, including those that had pledged these men to fight the Shadow along the Blight. Nengar and Bartu each carried a sword on his back and had another hanging at his saddlebow, and Bartu, shorter than the other two, had a cased horsebow and a quiver fastened to his saddle, too. Masema wore no visible weapons. The Prophet of the Lord Dragon Reborn needed none. Perrin was glad to see Gallenne watching the men Masema had left behind, for there was something about Masema that drew the eye. Maybe it was only knowing who he was, but that was more than enough. Masema stopped his rangy sorrel a few paces from Perrin. The Prophet was a dark frowning man of average size with a faded arrow-scar white on his cheek, in a worn brown woolen coat and a dark cloak with frayed edges. Masema cared nothing for appearances, least of all his own. At his back, Nengar and Bartu held a fever in their eyes, but Masema's deep-set, almost black eyes seemed as hot as coals in a forge, as though the breezes must soon fan them to a glow, and his smell was the jangled, darting sharpness of pure insanity. He ignored the Wise Ones and Aes Sedai with a scorn he did not bother to hide. Wise Ones were worse than Aes Sedai, in his view; they not only blasphemed by channeling the One Power, they were Aiel savages to boot, a double sin. The Winged Guards could have been just more shadows beneath the trees. "You are taking a picnic?" he said with a glance at the basket hanging from Perrin's saddle. Normally, Masema's voice was as intense as his eyes, but now it sounded wry, and his lip curled as his eyes traveled to Berelain. He had heard the rumors, of course.

ə weɪv ə ɹeɪdʒ ʃɑt θɹu pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i sizd ɑntu ɪt, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪt bæk. foʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn wɪð ðə ɹɛst, foʊldɪŋ ɪt taɪt. hɪz æŋɡɝ hæd wʌn tɑɹɡət, ən i wəd nɑt weɪst ɪt stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ ənʌðɝ. kætʃɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪɾɝz mud, stɛpɝ bɛɹɾ ɪz tiθ ət mæsiməz ɡɛldɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn hæd tə ɹeɪn ɪm ɪn ʃɑɹpli. "ðɛɹ wɝ dɑɹkhaʊnz hɪɹ ɪn ðə naɪt," hi sɛd, nɑt vɛɹi smuðli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd mænədʒ.

A wave of rage shot through Perrin, but he seized onto it, forcing it back. Folding it in with the rest, folding it tight. His anger had one target, and he would not waste it striking at another. Catching his rider's mood, Stepper bared his teeth at Masema's gelding, and Perrin had to rein him in sharply. "There were Darkhounds here in the night," he said, not very smoothly, but it was the best he could manage.

"ðeɪɹ ɡɔn, ən mɑsʊɝi dʌzn θɪŋk ðəl kʌm bæk, soʊ ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə wɝi." mæsimə dɪd nɑt smɛl wɝid. hi nɛvɝ smɛld ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp mædnəs. ðə sɔɹəl θɹʌst ɪz hɛɾ əɡɹɛsɪvli təwɔɹd stɛpɝ, bʌt mæsimə pʊld ɪm ʌp wɪð ə hɑɹʃ dʒɝk. hi ɹoʊd wɛl, mæsimə dɪd, bʌɾ i tʃɹiɾəd ɪz hɔɹsəz əz i dɪd pipəl. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, hi lʊkt ət mɑsʊɝi. pɝhæps ɪz ɡeɪz ɡɹu ə lɪɾəl hɑɾɝ, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. "ðə ʃædoʊ kən bi faʊn ɛvɹiwɛɹ," hi sɛd, ə hiɾəd pɹənaʊnsmən ʌv ənkwɛstʃənəbəl tʃɹuθ. "noʊ wʌn nid fɪɹ ðə ʃædoʊ hu fɑloʊz ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪz neɪm. ivən ɪn dɛθ ðəl faɪn ðə faɪnəl vɪktɝi ʌv ðə laɪt." mɑsʊɝiz mɛɹ ʃaɪɾ əz ðoʊ bɝn baɪ ðət ɡeɪz, jɛt mɑsʊɝi kəntʃɹoʊl ði ænəməl wɪð ə tʌtʃ ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz ən mɛt mæsiməz stɛɹ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnskɹəɾəbɪlɪti, əz kɑm əz ə fɹoʊzən pɑnd.

"They're gone, and Masuri doesn't think they'll come back, so there's no need to worry." Masema did not smell worried. He never smelled of anything except madness. The sorrel thrust his head aggressively toward Stepper, but Masema pulled him up with a harsh jerk. He rode well, Masema did, but he treated his horses as he did people. For the first time, he looked at Masuri. Perhaps his gaze grew a little hotter, if that was possible. "The Shadow can be found everywhere," he said, a heated pronouncement of unquestionable truth. "No one need fear the Shadow who follows the Lord Dragon Reborn, may the Light illumine his name. Even in death they will find the final victory of the Light." Masuri's mare shied as though burned by that gaze, yet Masuri controlled the animal with a touch on the reins and met Masema's stare with Aes Sedai inscrutability, as calm as a frozen pond.

nʌθɪŋ hɪntəd ðət ʃi hæd bɪn miɾɪŋ ðɪs mæn ɪn sikɹət. "fɪɹ ɪz ə jusfəl spɝ tə ðə wɪts, ən tə dɪtɝməneɪʃən, wən wɛl kəntʃɹoʊld. ɪf wɪv noʊ fɪɹ ʌv əɹ ɛnəmiz, ðət livz oʊnli kəntɛmpt, ən kəntɛmp lidz tə ði ɛnəmiz vɪktɝi." jə cʊɾə θɔt ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ tə ə sɪmpəl fɑɹmɝ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ mɛt bɪfɔɹ. ənʊɹə, wɑtʃɪŋ, lʊkt ə lɪɾəl ɪl. wɑz ʃi əfɹeɪd ðɛɹ sikɹət wəd kʌm aʊt? ðət ðɛɹ plænz fəɹ mæsimə kəd bi spɔɪld?

Nothing hinted that she had been meeting this man in secret. "Fear is a useful spur to the wits, and to determination, when well controlled. If we have no fear of our enemies, that leaves only contempt, and contempt leads to the enemy's victory." You could have thought she was speaking to a simple farmer she had never met before. Annoura, watching, looked a little ill. Was she afraid their secret would come out? That their plans for Masema could be spoiled?

mæsiməz lɪp kɝld əɡɛn, ɪn ə smaɪl, əɹ ə snɪɹ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim tə sis tə ɪɡzɪs fəɹ ɪm əz i tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən bæk tə pɛɹɪn. "sʌm ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən əv faʊn ə taʊn kɔl soʊ hæbɝ." ðət wɑz haʊ hi ɔlweɪz ɹəfɝd tə hɪz fɑloʊɝz: ðeɪ ɹɪli fɑloʊd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, nɑt hɪm. ðə fæk ðət mæsimə toʊld əm wʌt də ən wən ən haʊ wɑz dʒʌst ə dɪteɪl. "ə taɪɾi pleɪs ə θɹi əɹ fɔɹ θaʊzən pipəl, əbaʊɾ ə deɪ bæk, əɹ ə lɪɾəl lɛs, tə ðə saʊθ ən wɛst. ɪt simz ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə ði ilz pæθ, ən ðɛɹ kɹɑp wɑz ɡʊd læs jɪɹ dɪspaɪt ðə dʒɹaʊt. ðeɪv stɔɹhaʊzəz fʊl ə bɑɹli, mɪləɾ ən oʊts, ən ʌðɝ nidfəl θɪŋz, aɪ ʃəɾ ɪmædʒən. aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ɑn fɑɾɝ. fəɹ jəɹ mɛn əz wɛl əz jəɹ hɔɹsəz." "waɪ wəd ðɛɹ stɔɹhaʊzəz bi fʊl ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ?" bɹəleɪn lin fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə fɹaʊn, hɝ toʊn dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə dɪmænd, ən nɑt fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə dɪsbɪlif.

Masema's lip curled again, in a smile, or a sneer. The Aes Sedai seemed to cease to exist for him as he turned his attention back to Perrin. "Some of those who follow the Lord Dragon have found a town called So Habor." That was how he always referred to his followers: they really followed the Dragon Reborn, not him. The fact that Masema told them what do and when and how was just a detail. "A tidy place of three or four thousand people, about a day back, or a little less, to the south and west. It seems they were out of the Aiel's path, and their crop was good last year despite the drought. They have storehouses full of barley, millet and oats, and other needful things, I should imagine. I know you are running short on fodder. For your men as well as your horses." "Why would their storehouses be full this time of year?" Berelain leaned forward with a frown, her tone just short of a demand, and not far short of disbelief.

skaʊlɪŋ, nɛŋɡɝ pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz sæɾəl-sɔɹd. noʊ wʌn meɪd dɪmænz ə ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. noʊ wʌn daʊɾɪd hɪm, iðɝ. noʊ wʌn u wɪʃt tə lɪv. lɛðɝ kɹikt əz lænsɝz ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, bʌt nɛŋɡɝ ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. ðə smɛl ə mæsiməz mædnəs slaɪðɝɾ ən fleɪld ɪn pɛɹɪnz noʊz. mæsimə stʌɾid bɹəleɪn. hi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə nɛŋɡɝ əɹ ðə lænsɝz əɹ ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət mɛn maɪt stɑɹt kɪlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɛni moʊmənt. "ə mæɾɝ ʌv ɡɹid," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "əpɛɹənli ðə ɡɹeɪn tʃɹeɪɾɝz ə soʊ hæbɝ θɔt tə meɪk lɑɹdʒɝ pɹɑfəts baɪ hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ stɑk əntɪl wɪntɝ dʒɹoʊv pɹaɪsəz ʌp.

Scowling, Nengar put a hand to his saddle-sword. No one made demands of the Prophet of the Lord Dragon. No one doubted him, either. No one who wished to live. Leather creaked as lancers shifted their saddles, but Nengar ignored them. The smell of Masema's madness slithered and flailed in Perrin's nose. Masema studied Berelain. He seemed unaware of Nengar or the lancers or the possibility that men might start killing one another any moment. "A matter of greed," he said finally. "Apparently the grain traders of So Habor thought to make larger profits by holding their stock until winter drove prices up.

bʌt ðeɪ nɔɹməli sɛl wɛst, ɪndə ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, ən ɪvɛns ðəɹ ən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ əv meɪɾ əm fɪɹfəl ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ sɛn aʊt wɪl bi kɑnfəskeɪɾəd. ðɛɹ ɡɹiɾ əz lɛft əm wɪð fʊl stɔɹhaʊzəz ən ɛmpti pɝsɪz." ə noʊɾ ə sæɾəsfækʃən ɛntɝd mæsiməz vɔɪs. hi dɪspaɪzd ɡɹid. bʌt ðɛn, hi dɪspaɪzd ɛni hjumən wiknəs, ɡɹeɪɾ əɹ smɔl. "aɪ θɪŋk ðəl pɑɹt wɪð ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪn vɛɹi tʃipli, naʊ." pɛɹɪn smɛld ə tʃɹæp, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk ə wʊlfs noʊz. mæsimə hæɾ ɪz oʊn mɛn ən hɔɹsəz tə fid, ən noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ θɝoʊli ðeɪ hæd skaʊɝd ðə kʌntʃɹi ðeɪ kɹɔst, ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi ɪn mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ʃeɪp ðən pɛɹɪnz oʊn pipəl. waɪ hæd mæsimə nɑt sɛn ə fju θaʊzən ə hɪz fɑloʊɝz ɪndə ðɪs taʊn ən teɪkən wʌtɛvɝ ɪt hɛld? ə deɪ bæk. ðət wəd teɪk ɪm fɑɹðɝ fɹəm feɪl, ən meɪbi ɡɪv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ taɪm tə ɡeɪn ɡɹaʊn əɡɛn. wɑz ðət ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðɪs pəkjuljɝ ɔfɝ? əɹ ə fɝðɝ dɪleɪ tə kip mæsimə ɪn ðə wɛst, kloʊs tə hɪz sintʃæn fɹɛnz? "pɝhæps ðəɹ wɪl bi taɪm tə vɪzət ðɪs taʊn æftɝ maɪ waɪf ɪz fɹi." wʌns əɡɛn, pɛɹɪnz ɪɹz kɑt ðə feɪn saʊn ə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz muvɪŋ θɹu ðə fɔɹəs bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə wɛst, ðɪs taɪm, fɹəm ðə kæmp.

But they normally sell west, into Ghealdan and Amadicia, and events there and in Ebou Dar have made them fearful that anything they send out will be confiscated. Their greed has left them with full storehouses and empty purses." A note of satisfaction entered Masema's voice. He despised greed. But then, he despised any human weakness, great or small. "I think they will part with their grain very cheaply, now." Perrin smelled a trap, and it did not take a wolf's nose. Masema had his own men and horses to feed, and no matter how thoroughly they had scoured the country they crossed, they could not be in much better shape than Perrin's own people. Why had Masema not sent a few thousand of his followers into this town and taken whatever it held? A day back. That would take him farther from Faile, and maybe give the Shaido time to gain ground again. Was that the reason for this peculiar offer? Or a further delay to keep Masema in the west, close to his Seanchan friends? "Perhaps there will be time to visit this town after my wife is free." Once again, Perrin's ears caught the faint sound of men and horses moving through the forest before anyone else, coming from the west, this time, from the camp.

ɡælɛnz mɛsənʒɝ mʌst əv ɡæləp ðə hoʊl weɪ.

Gallenne's messenger must have galloped the whole way.

"jɔɹ waɪf," mæsimə sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs, dɝɛktɪŋ ə lʊk ət bɹəleɪn ðət meɪd pɛɹɪnz blʌd bɔɪl. ivən bɹəleɪn kʌlɝd, ðoʊ hɝ feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð. "du jə ɹɪli bɪliv jəl əv wɝɾ ə hɝ tədeɪ?"

"Your wife," Masema said in a flat voice, directing a look at Berelain that made Perrin's blood boil. Even Berelain colored, though her face remained smooth. "Do you really believe you will have word of her today?"

"aɪ du." pɛɹɪnz vɔɪs wɑz əz flæɾ əz mæsiməz, ən hɑɹɾɝ. hi klʌtʃt ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, ətɑp ðə hup-hændəlz ə bɹəleɪnz bæskət, tə kip fɹəm ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz æks. "fɹiɪŋ əɹ kʌmz fɝst. hɝ ən ði ʌðɝz. wi kən fɪl əɹ bɛliz tə bɝstɪŋ wʌns ðæts dʌn, bʌt ðət kʌmz fɝst." ðə hɔɹsəz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ wɝ ɑɾəbəl tə ɛvɹiwʌn, naʊ. ə lɔŋ laɪn ə lænsɝz əpɪɹd tə ðə wɛst, sɪftɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃæɾoʊd tʃɹiz wɪð ənʌðɝ maʊntəd laɪn bɪhaɪn ɪt, ðə ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz ən bɹɛstpleɪts ə min ɪntɝspɝst wɪð ðə ɡɹin stʃɹimɝz ən bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ʌv ɡildən.

"I do." Perrin's voice was as flat as Masema's, and harder. He clutched the pommel of his saddle, atop the hoop-handles of Berelain's basket, to keep from reaching for his axe. "Freeing her comes first. Her and the others. We can fill our bellies to bursting once that's done, but that comes first." The horses approaching were audible to everyone, now. A long line of lancers appeared to the west, sifting through the shadowed trees with another mounted line behind it, the red streamers and breastplates of Mayene interspersed with the green streamers and burnished breastplates of Ghealdan.

ðə laɪnz stʃɹɛtʃt fɹəm ɑpəzət pɛɹɪn daʊn bɪloʊ ðə mæs ə hɔɹsmən u wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɑn mæsimə. mɛn əfʊt ɡɑstɪd fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi, kæɹiɪŋ lɔŋ tu ɹɪvɝz baʊz. pɛɹɪn faʊn hɪmsɛlf hoʊpɪŋ ðət ðeɪ hæd nɑt stʃɹɪp ðə kæmp tu fɑɹ. stilɪŋ ðət sintʃæn peɪpɝ maɪɾ əv fɔɹs mæsiməz hænd, ən i wɑz ə vɛɾɝən ə faɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪɾ ən əɡɛns ði il. hi maɪɾ əv θɔt fɝðɝ əhɛd ðən sɪmpli ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊt tə faɪn bɹəleɪn. ɪt wɑz laɪk ənʌðɝ blæksmɪθs pʌzəl.

The lines stretched from opposite Perrin down below the mass of horsemen who were waiting on Masema. Men afoot ghosted from tree to tree, carrying long Two Rivers bows. Perrin found himself hoping that they had not stripped the camp too far. Stealing that Seanchan paper might have forced Masema's hand, and he was a veteran of fighting along the Blight and against the Aiel. He might have thought further ahead than simply riding out to find Berelain. It was like another blacksmith's puzzle.

muv wʌn pis tə ʃɪft ənʌðɝ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ ə θɝd slɪp fɹi. ə kæmp wɪð wikən dɪfɛndɝz kəd bi oʊvɝɹʌn, ən ɪn ðiz wʊdz, nʌmbɝz kəd kaʊn fəɹ əz mʌtʃ əz u hæd pipəl tʃænəlɪŋ.

Move one piece to shift another just enough to let a third slip free. A camp with weakened defenders could be overrun, and in these woods, numbers could count for as much as who had people channeling.

dɪd mæsimə wɑnə kip ɪz sikɹəɾ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ pʊɾɪŋ ə sil tə ɪt hɪɹ ən naʊ? pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd muvd wʌn hæn tə ɹɛst ɑn ɪz æks, bʌɾ i lɛft ɪt ðɛɹ. əmʌŋ ðə mæs ə mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz, hɔɹsəz muv nɝvəsli ət tʌɡz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz, mɛn ʃaʊɾəd ən weɪvd wɛpənz, bʌt mæsimə hɪmsɛlf stʌɾid ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ lænsɝz ən boʊmən wɪð noʊ tʃeɪnʒ ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən, niðɝ mɔɹ daʊɝ nɔɹ lɛs.

Did Masema want to keep his secret enough to try putting a seal to it here and now? Perrin realized that he had moved one hand to rest on his axe, but he left it there. Among the mass of Masema's followers, horses moved nervously at tugs from their riders, men shouted and waved weapons, but Masema himself studied the oncoming lancers and bowmen with no change of expression, neither more dour nor less.

ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn bɝdz hɑpɪŋ fɹəm bɹæntʃ tə bɹæntʃ. ðə smɛl ə hɪm ɹɪθ mædli, əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ.

They might have been birds hopping from branch to branch. The smell of him writhed madly, unchanging.

"wʌɾ ɪz dʌn tə sɝv ðə laɪt, mʌs bi dʌn," hi sɛd wən ðə nukʌmɝz hɔltəd, səm tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ. ðət wɑz izi ɹeɪnʒ fəɹ ə tu ɹɪvɝz boʊmən, ən mæsimə hæd sin dɛmənstʃɹeɪʃənz, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðət bɹɔdhɛd ʃæfs maɪt bi eɪmd əɾ ɪz hɑɹt. "ɔl ɛls ɪz dʒɹɔs ən tʃɹæʃ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn ɡoʊldeɪniz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪz dʒɹɔs ən tʃɹæʃ!" dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz sɔɹəl ɝaʊnd wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, hi hɛɾəd bæk təwɔɹɾ ɪz weɪɾɪŋ mɛn tʃɹeɪl baɪ nɛŋɡɝ ən bɑɹɾu, ɔl θɹi pʊʃɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɪθaʊɾ ə kɛɹ fəɹ bɹoʊkən lɛɡz əɹ bɹoʊkən hɛdz. ðə weɪɾɪŋ kʌmpəni fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪnd, ə mɑb floʊɪŋ saʊθ, naʊ. ə fju mɛn ət ðə teɪl ɛn stɑp tə dʒɹæɡ ə lɪmp ʃeɪp fɹəm ʌndɝ ði ɪnʒɝd hɔɹs ən pʊt ði ænəməl aʊɾ ʌv ɪts mɪzɝi wɪð ə kwɪk slæʃ ʌv ə dæɡɝ. ðən ðeɪ bɪɡæn ɡʌɾɪŋ ən bʊtʃɝɪŋ. ðət mʌtʃ mit kəd nɑt bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ tə weɪst.

"What is done to serve the Light, must be done," he said when the newcomers halted, some two hundred paces away. That was easy range for a Two Rivers bowman, and Masema had seen demonstrations, but he gave no sign that broadhead shafts might be aimed at his heart. "All else is dross and trash. Remember that, Lord Perrin Goldeneyes. Everything else is dross and trash!" Jerking his sorrel around without another word, he headed back toward his waiting men trailed by Nengar and Bartu, all three pushing their horses without a care for broken legs or broken heads. The waiting company fell in behind, a mob flowing south, now. A few men at the tail end stopped to drag a limp shape from under the injured horse and put the animal out of its misery with a quick slash of a dagger. Then they began gutting and butchering. That much meat could not be allowed to go to waste.

ðə ɹaɪɾɝ, ðeɪ lɛft wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd dʒɹɑp hɪm.

The rider, they left where they had dropped him.

"hi bɪlivz ɛvɹi wɝɾ i sɛz," ənʊɹə bɹiðd, "bʌt wɛɹ dʌz ɪz bɪlif lɛd hɪm?" pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝd æskɪŋ əɹ stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt wɛɹ ʃi θɔt mæsiməz bɪlif wɑz liɾɪŋ hɪm, wɛɹ ʃi wɑntəd tə lid hɪm, bʌt ʃi sʌɾənli pʊɾ ɑn ðəɾ ɪmpɛnətʃɹəbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm. ðə tɪp ə hɝ ʃɑɹp noʊz hæd tɝn ɹɛd fɹəm ðə koʊld; ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm wɪð ə lɛvəl stɛɹ. jə kəd pɹaɪ ðət dɑɹkhaʊnd-mɑɹk stoʊn aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɛɹ-hændəɾ əz izəli əz ɡɛɾ ən ænsɝ fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɔɹ ðət lʊk. hi wəɾ əv tə liv kwɛstʃənz tə bɹəleɪn.

"He believes every word he says," Annoura breathed, "but where does his belief lead him?" Perrin considered asking her straight out where she thought Masema's belief was leading him, where she wanted to lead him, but she suddenly put on that impenetrable Aes Sedai calm. The tip of her sharp nose had turned red from the cold; she regarded him with a level stare. You could pry that Darkhound-marked stone out of the ground bare-handed as easily as get an answer from an Aes Sedai who wore that look. He would have to leave questions to Berelain.

ðə mæn u hæd bɹɔt ðə lænsɝz sʌɾənli spɝɾ ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd. ə ʃɔɹt kɑmpæk fɛloʊ ɪn ə sɪlvɝ-pleɪɾəd bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən ə hɛlmət wɪð ə bɑɹd feɪsɡɑɹɾ ən θɹi ʃɔɹt waɪt plumz, dʒɝɑɹɾ ɑɹɡændə wɑz ə tʌf mæn, ə soʊlʒɝ u hæd wɝkt ɪz weɪ ʌp fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm, əɡɛnst ɔl ɑdz, tə bɪkʌm ðə fɝs kæptən ʌv æliændɝz bɑɾiɡɑɹd. hi hæd noʊ laɪkɪŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn, hu hæd bɹɔɾ ɪz kwin saʊθ fəɹ noʊ ɡʊd ɹizən ən ɡɑɾən əɹ kɪdnæpt, bʌt pɛɹɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə stɑp ən meɪk ɪz ɹɪspɛks tə bɹəleɪn, pɝhæps kənfɝ wɪð ɡælɛn. ɑɹɡændə hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ɡælɛn, ən ɔfən spɛn taɪm wɪð ɪm boʊθ smoʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ paɪps. ɪnstɛd, ðə ɹoʊn flaʊndɝd pæs pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, ɑɹɡændə dɪɡɪŋ ɪz hilz ɪndə ði ænəməlz saɪdz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs mɔɹ spid.

The man who had brought the lancers suddenly spurred his horse forward. A short compact fellow in a silver-plated breastplate and a helmet with a barred faceguard and three short white plumes, Gerard Arganda was a tough man, a soldier who had worked his way up from the bottom, against all odds, to become the First Captain of Alliandre's bodyguard. He had no liking for Perrin, who had brought his queen south for no good reason and gotten her kidnapped, but Perrin expected him to stop and make his respects to Berelain, perhaps confer with Gallenne. Arganda had a great deal of respect for Gallenne, and often spent time with him both smoking their pipes. Instead, the roan floundered past Perrin and the others, Arganda digging his heels into the animal's sides, trying to force more speed.

wən pɛɹɪn sɔ wɛɹ ðə mæn wɑz hɛɾɪŋ, hi ʌndɝstʊd. ə sɪŋɡəl hɔɹsmən ɑn ə maʊsɛkʌlɝɾ ænəməl wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ fɹəm ði ist əɾ ə stɛɾi wɔk, ən bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən il ʃʌfəld əlɔŋ ɑn snoʊʃuz.

When Perrin saw where the man was heading, he understood. A single horseman on a mousecolored animal was approaching from the east at a steady walk, and beside him, an Aiel shuffled along on snowshoes.

tʃæptɝ eɪt

CHAPTER 8

wɝlpulz ə kʌlɝ pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz i hæd muvd əntɪl i faʊn hɪmsɛlf kɹaʊtʃt oʊvɝ stɛpɝz nɛk, stʃɹikɪŋ æftɝ ɑɹɡændə. ðə snoʊ wɑz noʊ lɛs dip, ðə ɡɹaʊnd noʊ smuðɝ, ðə laɪt noʊ bɛɾɝ, bʌt stɛpɝ ɹeɪs θɹu ðə ʃædoʊz, ənwɪlɪŋ tə lɛt ðə ɹoʊn steɪ ɪn ðə lɛd, ən pɛɹɪn ɝdʒd ɪm tə ɹʌn fæstɝ. ði əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɹaɪɾɝ wɑz ɛlaɪəs, hɪz bɪɹd fæn aʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɛst, ə bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæt kæstɪŋ ɪz feɪs ɪn ʃædoʊz ən ɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk. ði il wɑz wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz, wɪð ə dɑɹk ʃoʊufə ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛɾ ən ə waɪt kloʊk, juz fəɹ haɪɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə snoʊ, wɔɹn oʊvɝ əɹ koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ʌv ɡɹeɪz ən bɹaʊnz ən ɡɹinz. ɛlaɪəs ən wʌn meɪɾən, wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝz, mɛn feɪl hæd bɪn faʊnd. ɪt hæd tə.

Whirlpools of Color Perrin did not realize he had moved until he found himself crouched over Stepper's neck, streaking after Arganda. The snow was no less deep, the ground no smoother, the light no better, but Stepper raced through the shadows, unwilling to let the roan stay in the lead, and Perrin urged him to run faster. The approaching rider was Elyas, his beard fanned out over his chest, a broad-brimmed hat casting his face in shadows and his fur-lined cloak hanging down his back. The Aiel was one of the Maidens, with a dark shoufa wrapped around her head and a white cloak, used for hiding against the snow, worn over her coat and breeches of grays and browns and greens. Elyas and one Maiden, without the others, meant Faile had been found. It had to.

ɑɹɡændə ɹæn ɪz hɔɹs wɪθaʊɾ ə kɛɹ fəɹ wɛðɝ i bɹoʊk ðə ɹoʊnz nɛk əɹ ɪz oʊn, lipɪŋ stoʊn aʊtkɹɑps, splæʃɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊ əɾ ə nɪɹ-ɡæləp, bʌt stɛpɝ oʊvɝtʊk ɪm dʒʌst əz i ɹitʃt ɛlaɪəs ən dɪmændəɾ ɪn ə hɑɹʃ vɔɪs, "dɪd jə si ðə kwin, mækɛɹə? ɪz ʃi əlaɪv? tɛl mi, mæn!" ðə meɪɾən, ɛləəndə, hɝ sʌn-dɑɹkən feɪs ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə pɛɹɪn. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn mɛn fəɹ ə ɡɹiɾɪŋ, əɹ sɪmpəθi, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ bɹoʊk əɹ skɪmɪŋ stʃɹaɪd. wɪð ɛlaɪəs tə meɪk ɪz ɹipɔɹt tə pɛɹɪn, ʃi wəd kæɹi hɝz tə ðə waɪz wʌnz.

Arganda ran his horse without a care for whether he broke the roan's neck or his own, leaping stone outcrops, splashing through the snow at a near-gallop, but Stepper overtook him just as he reached Elyas and demanded in a harsh voice, "Did you see the queen, Machera? Is she alive? Tell me, man!" The Maiden, Elienda, her sun-darkened face expressionless, raised a hand to Perrin. It might have been meant for a greeting, or sympathy, but she never broke her skimming stride. With Elyas to make his report to Perrin, she would carry hers to the Wise Ones.

"juv faʊn hɝ?" pɛɹɪnz θɹoʊt wɑz sʌɾənli dʒɹaɪ əz sænd. hi hæd weɪɾəd soʊ lɔŋ fəɹ ðɪs.

"You've found her?" Perrin's throat was suddenly dry as sand. He had waited so long for this.

ɑɹɡændə snɑɹəl saʊnləsli θɹu ðə stil bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlməts feɪsɡɑɹd, noʊɪŋ ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑɾ æskɪŋ æftɝ æliændɝ.

Arganda snarled soundlessly through the steel bars of his helmet's faceguard, knowing that Perrin was not asking after Alliandre.

"wi faʊn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wiv bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd kɛɹfəli, boʊθ hænz ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl. ivən ɛlaɪəs, ðə feɪbəld lɔŋ tuθ u hæd lɪvd ən ɹʌn wɪð wʊlvz, wɑz ʃoʊɪŋ ðə stʃɹeɪn ə tu mɛni maɪlz ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf slip. hɪz hoʊl feɪs sæɡd wɪð ə wɪɹinəs ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ ðə ɡoʊldən-jɛloʊ ɡloʊ ʌv ɪz aɪz bɪniθ ɪz hæt bɹɪm. ɡɹeɪ stʃɹikt ɪz θɪk bɪɹɾ ən ðə hɛɹ ðəɾ i wɔɹ hæŋɪŋ tə hɪz weɪst ən taɪd wɪð ə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk, ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns pɛɹɪn hæd noʊn hɪm, hi lʊkt oʊld. "ðeɪɹ kæmpt ɝaʊn ə fɛɹ-saɪz taʊn ðeɪ tʊk, ɪn ɹɪdʒ kʌntʃɹi nɪɹ fɔɹɾi maɪlz fɹəm hɪɹ. ðeɪv ɡɑt noʊ sɛntʃɹiz tə spik ə kloʊs ɪn, ən ðoʊz fɝðɝ aʊt sim tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ pɹɪznɝz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, soʊ wi ɡɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə ɡʊd lʊk. bʌt pɛɹɪn, ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ə ðɛm ðən wi θɔt. ət lis naɪn əɹ tɛn sɛps, ðə meɪɾənz seɪ. kaʊntɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn - foʊks ɪn waɪt, ɛniweɪ - ðəɹ kəd bi əz mɛni pipəl ɪn ðət kæmp əz ɪn min əɹ ɛbu dɑɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ mɛni spɪɹ faɪɾɝz, bʌt tɛn θaʊzən maɪt bi ɑn ðə loʊ saɪd fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ sɔ."

"We found the Shaido we've been following," Elyas said carefully, both hands on the pommel of his saddle. Even Elyas, the fabled Long Tooth who had lived and run with wolves, was showing the strain of too many miles and not enough sleep. His whole face sagged with a weariness emphasized by the golden-yellow glow of his eyes beneath his hat brim. Gray streaked his thick beard and the hair that he wore hanging to his waist and tied with a leather cord at the nape of his neck, and for the first time since Perrin had known him, he looked old. "They're camped around a fair-sized town they took, in ridge country near forty miles from here. They've got no sentries to speak of close in, and those further out seem to be watching for prisoners trying to escape more than anything else, so we got near enough for a good look. But Perrin, there are more of them than we thought. At least nine or ten septs, the Maidens say. Counting gai'shain - folks in white, anyway - there could be as many people in that camp as in Mayene or Ebou Dar. I don't know how many spear fighters, but ten thousand might be on the low side from what I saw."

nɑts ə dɛspɝeɪʃən twɪstəɾ ən taɪɾənd ɪn pɛɹɪnz stʌmək. hɪz maʊθ wɑz soʊ dʒɹaɪ hi kəd nɑɾ əv spoʊkən hæd feɪl mɝækjələsli əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. tɛn θaʊzən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ, ən ivən wivɝz ən sɪlvɝsmɪθs ən oʊl mɛn u pæs ðɛɹ deɪz ɹɛmənɪsɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪd wəd pɪk ʌp ə spɪɹ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ətækt. hi hæd fjuɝ ðən tu θaʊzən lænsɝz, ən ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn oʊvɝmætʃt əɡɛnst ən ikwəl nʌmbɝ ʌv il. fjuɝ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, hu kəd ɹik hævək wɪð ðɛɹ baʊz əɾ ə dɪstəns bʌt nɑt stɑp tɛn θaʊzənd. ðət mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ wəd ʃɹɛd mæsiməz mɝɾɝəs ɹæbəl laɪk ə kæt slɔɾɝɪŋ ə nɛst ə maɪs. ivən kaʊntɪŋ ði æʃəmən ən ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. . . . ɛdʒɹə ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz wɝ hɑɹdli dʒɛnɝəs ɪn wʌt ðeɪ toʊld ɪm əbaʊt waɪz wʌnz, bʌɾ i nu tɛn sɛps maɪɾ əv fɪfti wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl, meɪbi mɔɹ.

Knots of desperation twisted and tightened in Perrin's stomach. His mouth was so dry he could not have spoken had Faile miraculously appeared in front of him. Ten thousand algai'd'siswai, and even weavers and silversmiths and old men who passed their days reminiscing in the shade would pick up a spear if they were attacked. He had fewer than two thousand lancers, and they would have been overmatched against an equal number of Aiel. Fewer than three hundred Two Rivers men, who could wreak havoc with their bows at a distance but not stop ten thousand. That many Shaido would shred Masema's murderous rabble like a cat slaughtering a nest of mice. Even counting the Asha'man and the Wise Ones and Aes Sedai. . . . Edarra and the other Wise Ones were hardly generous in what they told him about Wise Ones, but he knew ten septs might have fifty women who could channel, maybe more.

meɪbi fjuɝ, tu - ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɛt nʌmbɝ - bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf fjuɝ tə meɪk ə dɪfɝəns.

Maybe fewer, too - there was no set number - but not enough fewer to make a difference.

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, hi stʃɹæŋɡəl ðə dɪspɛɹ wɛlɪŋ ʌp ɪn hɪm, skwizd əntɪl oʊnli ɹaɪðɪŋ fɪləməns ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ ɪz æŋɡɝ tə bɝn ʌp. ə hæmɝ hæd noʊ pleɪs ɪn ɪt fəɹ dɪspɛɹ. tɛn sɛps əɹ ðə hoʊl ʃeɪɾoʊ klæn, ðeɪ stɪl hæd feɪl, ən i stɪl hæd tə faɪn ə weɪ. "wʌt dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni ðəɹ ɑɹ?" ɛɹæm dɪmændəd. "wɛn tʃɹɑləks keɪm tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðəɹ wɝ θaʊzənz, tɛnz ə θaʊzənz, bʌt wi kɪld əm dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ʃeɪɾoʊ kæn bi wɝs ðən tʃɹɑləks." pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt, sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðə mæn ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm, nɑt tə mɛnʃən bɹəleɪn ən ɡælɛn ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪn ɪz heɪs tə ɹitʃ ɛlaɪəs, hi hæd ʃʌɾ aʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. dɪmli vɪzəbəl θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ðə mɛn ɑɹɡændə hæd bɹɔɾ aʊt tə kənfɹʌn mæsimə stɪl hɛl ðɛɹ ɹʌf laɪnz, bʌt bɹəleɪnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd wɑz fɔɹmɪŋ ə lus ɹɪŋ sɛntɝɾ ɑn ɛlaɪəs ən feɪsɪŋ aʊtwɝd. ðə waɪz wʌnz stʊɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɝkəl, lɪsnɪŋ tə ɛləəndə wɪð ɡɹeɪv feɪsəz. ʃi spoʊk ɪn ə loʊ mɝmɝ, səmtaɪmz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. hɝ vju ʌv mæɾɝz wɑz noʊ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ɛlaɪəsəz. hi mʌst əv lɔs ðə bæskəɾ ɪn ɪz heɪst, əɹ θɹoʊn ɪɾ əweɪ, kəz ɪt hʌŋ fɹəm bɹəleɪnz sæɾəl naʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ə lʊk ʌv. . . kəɾ ɪt bi sɪmpəθi, ɑn əɹ feɪs? bɝn hɪm, hi wɑz tu taɪɝd tə θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt. oʊnli, naʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ, hi hæd tə θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt. hɪz nɛks mɪsteɪk maɪt bi ðə læst, fəɹ feɪl.

With an effort, he strangled the despair welling up in him, squeezed until only writhing filaments remained for his anger to burn up. A hammer had no place in it for despair. Ten septs or the whole Shaido clan, they still had Faile, and he still had to find a way. "What does it matter how many there are?" Aram demanded. "When Trollocs came to the Two Rivers, there were thousands, tens of thousands, but we killed them just the same. Shaido can't be worse than Trollocs." Perrin blinked, surprised to find the man right behind him, not to mention Berelain and Gallenne and the Aes Sedai. In his haste to reach Elyas, he had shut out everything else. Dimly visible through the trees, the men Arganda had brought out to confront Masema still held their rough lines, but Berelain's bodyguard was forming a loose ring centered on Elyas and facing outward. The Wise Ones stood outside the circle, listening to Elienda with grave faces. She spoke in a low murmur, sometimes shaking her head. Her view of matters was no brighter than Elyas's. He must have lost the basket in his haste, or thrown it away, because it hung from Berelain's saddle now. There was a look of. . . could it be sympathy, on her face? Burn him, he was too tired to think straight. Only, now more than ever, he had to think straight. His next mistake might be the last, for Faile.

"weɪ aɪ hɝɾ ɪt, tɪŋkɝ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd kwaɪətli, "ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm tə jə ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən jə mænədʒ tə kætʃ əm ɪn ə vaɪs. juv ɛni fænsi plænz fəɹ kætʃɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪn ə vaɪs?" ɛɹæm ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm sʌlənli. ɛlaɪəs hæd noʊn ɪm bɪfɔɹ i pɪkt ʌp ə sɔɹd, ən ɛɹæm dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðət taɪm, dɪspaɪɾ ɪz bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd kloʊðz.

"Way I heard it, Tinker," Elyas said quietly, "the Trollocs came to you in the Two Rivers, and you managed to catch them in a vise. You have any fancy plans for catching the Shaido in a vise?" Aram glared at him sullenly. Elyas had known him before he picked up a sword, and Aram disliked being reminded of that time, despite his brightly colored clothes.

"tɛn sɛps əɹ fɪfti," ɑɹɡændə ɡɹaʊld, "ðɛɹ mʌs bi səm weɪ tə fɹi ðə kwin. ən ði ʌðɝz, ʌv kɔɹs. ən ði ʌðɝz." hɪz hɑɹd-bɪɾən feɪs wɑz kɹist ɪn ə skaʊl ʌv æŋɡɝ, jɛɾ i smɛl fɹæntɪk, ə fɑks ɹɛɾi tʃu ɔf ɪts oʊn lɛɡ tə ɪskeɪp ə tʃɹæp. "wɪl . . . ? wɪl ðeɪ æksɛpt ə ɹænsəm?" ðə ɡildænɪn lʊkt ɝaʊn əntɪl i faʊn mɑɹlaɪn kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz. ʃi mænədʒd ə stɛɾi stʃɹaɪɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə snoʊ, nɑt stæɡɝɪŋ ɪn ðə list. ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛniwɛɹ tə bi sin əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, nɔɹ ɛləəndə. "wɪl ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ teɪk ə ɹænsəm . . . waɪz wʌn?" ɑɹɡændəz ɑnɝɪfɪk hæd ðə saʊn ʌv ən æftɝθɑt. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪliv ði il wɪð əm hæɾ ɛni nɑlədʒ ə ðə kɪdnæpɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə teɪn ɪn ɪm ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ il. "aɪ kænɑt seɪ." mɑɹlaɪn sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs ɪz toʊn. ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, ʃi stʊd lʊkɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn ɹæðɝ ðən ɑɹɡændə. ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz lʊks wɛɹ ə wʊmən weɪɾ ən mɛʒɝd jə tɪl ʃi cʊɾə soʊn jə ə suɾ ə kloʊðz əɹ toʊl jə wən jəɹ smɔlkloʊðz wɝ læst wɑʃt. ɪt wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm ənkʌmftəɹbəl bæk wən i hæd hæd taɪm fəɹ sətʃ θɪŋz. wən ʃi spoʊk əɡɛn, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɔfɝɪŋ ædvaɪs ɪn əɹ toʊn, mɪɹli ə sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fæks. ʃi maɪɾ ivən əv mɛn ɪt soʊ. "jɔɹ wɛtləndɝ peɪɪŋ ə ɹænsəm ɡoʊz əɡɛnst əɹ kʌstəm. ɡeɪʃeɪn meɪ bi ɡɪvən əz ə ɡɪft, əɹ tʃɹeɪɾɪd fəɹ ʌðɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn , bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ænəməlz tə bi soʊld. jɛɾ ɪt simz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɑloʊ dʒiɾəb.

"Ten septs or fifty," Arganda growled, "there must be some way to free the Queen. And the others, of course. And the others." His hard-bitten face was creased in a scowl of anger, yet he smelled frantic, a fox ready chew off its own leg to escape a trap. "Will . . . ? Will they accept a ransom?" The Ghealdanin looked around until he found Marline coming through the Winged Guards. She managed a steady stride in spite of the snow, not staggering in the least. The other Wise Ones were no longer anywhere to be seen among the trees, nor Elienda. "Will these Shaido take a ransom . . . Wise One?" Arganda's honorific had the sound of an afterthought. He no longer believed the Aiel with them had any knowledge of the kidnapping, but there was a taint in him regarding Aiel. "I cannot say." Marline seemed not to notice his tone. Arms folded across her chest, she stood looking at Perrin rather than Arganda. It was one of those looks where a woman weighed and measured you till she could have sewn you a suit of clothes or told you when your smallclothes were last washed. It would have made him uncomfortable back when he had had time for such things. When she spoke again, there was nothing of offering advice in her tone, merely a setting out of the facts. She might even have meant it so. "Your wetlander paying of ransom goes against our custom. Gai'shain may be given as a gift, or traded for other gai'shain , but they are not animals to be sold. Yet it seems the Shaido no longer follow ji'e'tob.

ðeɪ meɪk wɛtləndɝz ɡeɪʃeɪn ən teɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊnli ðə fɪfθ. ðeɪ meɪ sɛɾ ə pɹaɪs."

They make wetlanders gai'shain and take everything instead of only the fifth. They may set a price."

"maɪ dʒuəlz ɑɹ ət jəɹ dɪspoʊzəl, pɛɹɪn," bɹəleɪn pʊɾ ɪn, hɝ vɔɪs stɛɾi ən əɹ feɪs fɝm. "ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, ɡɹeɪɾi əɹ nil kən fɛtʃ mɔɹ fɹəm min. ɡoʊld, əz wɛl." ɡælɛn klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ɔltɑɹənz ɑɹ juz tə mɝɔɾɝz, maɪ leɪɾi, neɪbɝɪŋ noʊbəlz ən bɹɪɡænz əlaɪk," hi sɛd sloʊli, slæpɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz əɡɛnst ɪz pɑm. ɔlðoʊ ɹɪlʌktən tə kɑntʃɹə dɪk bɹəleɪn, hi klɪɹli ɪntɛndəd tə ɛniweɪ. "ðɛɹz noʊ lɔ ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, ɪksɛpt wʌt ðə loʊkəl lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi sɛz. noʊbəl əɹ kɑmən, ðəɹ əkʌstəm tə peɪɪŋ ɔf ɛniwʌn ðeɪ kæn faɪɾ ɔf, ən kwɪk tə tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns. ɪt ɡoʊz əɡɛnst ɹizən ðət nʌn ə ðɛm tʃɹaɪd tə baɪ seɪfti, jɛt wiv sin nʌθɪŋ bʌt ɹuənz ɪn ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊz pæθ, hɝɾ ə nʌθɪŋ bʌt pɪlɪdʒ ɹaɪt daʊn tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ meɪ æksɛpt ən ɔfɝ ə ɹænsəm, ən ivən teɪk ɪt, bʌt kən ðeɪ bi tʃɹʌstɪd tə ɡɪv ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ɹɪtɝn? dʒʌs meɪkɪŋ ði ɔfɝ ɡɪvz əweɪ əɹ wʌn ɹil ædvæntɪdʒ, ðət ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ wəɹ hɪɹ." ənʊɹə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, ðə bɛɹəs muvmənt, bʌt ɡælɛnz wʌn aɪ kɑɾ ɪt, ən i fɹaʊnd. "ju dɪsəɡɹi, ənʊɹə sədaɪ?" hi æsk pəlaɪtli. ən wɪð ə hɪn ə sɝpɹaɪz.

"My jewels are at your disposal, Perrin," Berelain put in, her voice steady and her face firm. "If necessary, Grady or Neald can fetch more from Mayene. Gold, as well." Gallenne cleared his throat. "Altarans are used to marauders, my Lady, neighboring nobles and brigands alike," he said slowly, slapping his reins against his palm. Although reluctant to contra dict Berelain, he clearly intended to anyway. "There's no law this far from Ebou Dar, except what the local lord or lady says. Noble or common, they're accustomed to paying off anyone they can't fight off, and quick to tell the difference. It goes against reason that none of them tried to buy safety, yet we've seen nothing but ruins in these Shaido's path, heard of nothing but pillage right down to the ground. They may accept an offer of ransom, and even take it, but can they be trusted to give anything in return? Just making the offer gives away our one real advantage, that they don't know we are here." Annoura shook her head slightly, the barest movement, but Gallenne's one eye caught it, and he frowned. "You disagree, Annoura Sedai?" he asked politely. And with a hint of surprise.

ðə ɡɹeɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊs dɪfəɾənt ət taɪmz, ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ə sɪstɝ, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ væsəleɪɾɪd əbaʊt spikɪŋ ʌp wən ʃi dɪsəɡɹid wɪð ædvaɪs ɔfɝd tə bɹəleɪn.

The Gray was almost diffident at times, especially for a sister, but she never vacillated about speaking up when she disagreed with advice offered to Berelain.

ðɪs taɪm ənʊɹə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðoʊ, ən kʌvɝd baɪ pʊlɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf ən ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðə foʊlz wɪð kɛɹ. ɪt wɑz klʌmzi ʌv hɝ; ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ hiɾ əɹ koʊld wən ðeɪ tʃoʊz, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əntʌtʃt wən ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn əm wɑz dʒɹɛntʃt wɪð swɛɾ əɹ faɪɾɪŋ tə stɑp ðɛɹ tiθ tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu peɪɾ ətɛnʃən tə ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ wɑz baɪɪŋ taɪm tə θɪŋk, juʒəwəli əbaʊt haʊ tə haɪd wʌt ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. ɡlænsɪŋ təwɔɹd mɑɹlaɪn wɪð ə smɔl fɹaʊn, ʃi faɪnəli ɹitʃt ə dɪsɪʒən, ən ðə slaɪt kɹis ɪn əɹ fɔɹhɛd vænɪʃt.

This time Annoura hesitated, though, and covered by pulling her cloak around herself and arranging the folds with care. It was clumsy of her; Aes Sedai could ignore heat or cold when they chose, remaining untouched when everyone around them was drenched with sweat or fighting to stop their teeth chattering. An Aes Sedai who paid attention to the temperature was buying time to think, usually about how to hide what she was thinking. Glancing toward Marline with a small frown, she finally reached a decision, and the slight crease in her forehead vanished.

"nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən ɪz ɔlweɪz bɛɾɝ ðən faɪɾɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn kul tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛns, "æn ɪn nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən, tʃɹʌst ɪz ɔlweɪz ə mæɾɝ ə ðə pɹikɔʃənz, jɛs? wi mʌs kənsɪɾɝ wɪð kɛɹ ðə pɹikɔʃənz ðət mʌs bi teɪkən. ðəɹ ɪz ɔlsoʊ ðə kwɛstʃən ə hu ɪz tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðɛm. waɪz wʌnz meɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi sækɹoʊsæŋkt, sɪns ðeɪ tʊk pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə bæɾəl ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. ə sɪstɝ, əɹ ə ɡɹup ə sɪstɝz, maɪt bi bɛɾɝ, jɛɾ ivən ðət mʌst əv kɛɹfəl ɝeɪnʒmənt.

"Negotiation is always better than fighting," she said in cool Taraboner accents, "and in negotiation, trust is always a matter of the precautions, yes? We must consider with care the precautions that must be taken. There is also the question of who is to approach them. Wise Ones may no longer be sacrosanct, since they took part in the battle at Dumai's Wells. A sister, or a group of sisters, might be better, yet even that must have careful arrangement.

"aɪ maɪsɛlf æm wɪlɪŋ tə -"

"I myself am willing to -"

"noʊ ɹænsəm," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən wən ɛvɹiwʌn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, moʊst ɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən, ənʊɹə wɪð əɹ feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl, hi sɛɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn, ɪn ə hɑɹɾɝ vɔɪs. "noʊ ɹænsəm." hi wəd nɑt peɪ ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ fəɹ meɪkɪŋ feɪl sʌfɝ. ʃi wəd bi əfɹeɪd, ən ðeɪ hæd tə peɪ fəɹ ðæt, nɑt pɹɑfət fɹəm ɪt. bɪsaɪdz, ɡælɛn hæd ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɪt. nʌθɪŋ pɛɹɪn hæd sin, ɪn ɔltɑɹə əɹ ɑmɑdɪʃiə əɹ bɪfɔɹ ðəɾ ɪn kɛɹhin, soʊ mʌtʃ əz hɪntəd ðət ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəd bi tʃɹʌstɪd tə kip ɛni bɑɹɡən. əz wɛl tʃɹʌst ɹæts ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪn bɪnz ən kʌtwɝmz wɪð ðə hɑɹvəst. "ɛlaɪəs, aɪ wɑnə si ðɛɹ kæmp." wən i wɑz ə bɔɪ hi hæd noʊn ə blaɪn mæn, næt tɔɹfɪn wɪð ɪz ɹɪŋkəl feɪs ən θɪn waɪt hɛɹ, hu kəd dɪsəsɛmbəl ɛni blæksmɪθs pʌzəl baɪ tʌtʃ. fəɹ jɪɹz pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə lɝn haʊ tə dupləkeɪt ðət fit, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ kʊd. hi hæd tə si haʊ ðə pisəz fɪt təɡɛðɝ bɪfɔɹ i kəd meɪk sɛns ə ðɛm. "ɛɹæm, faɪnd ɡɹeɪɾi ən tɛl ɪm tə mit mi əz fæst əz i kæn, ət ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd." ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə kɔl ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðeɪ ɝaɪvd ət ði ɛn ʌv itʃ dʒʌmp, ən dɪpɑɹɾəd fɹəm fəɹ ðə nɛkst. ɪt wɑz iziɝ fəɹ ði æʃəmən tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ə pleɪs ɔlɹɛɾi tʌtʃt baɪ wʌn ðeɪ hæd woʊvən bɪfɔɹ.

"No ransom," Perrin said, and when everyone stared at him, most in consternation, Annoura with her face unreadable, he said it again, in a harder voice. "No ransom." He would not pay these Shaido for making Faile suffer. She would be afraid, and they had to pay for that, not profit from it. Besides, Gallenne had the right of it. Nothing Perrin had seen, in Altara or Amadicia or before that in Cairhien, so much as hinted that the Shaido could be trusted to keep any bargain. As well trust rats in the grain bins and cutworms with the harvest. "Elyas, I want to see their camp." When he was a boy he had known a blind man, Nat Torfinn with his wrinkled face and thin white hair, who could disassemble any blacksmith's puzzle by touch. For years Perrin tried to learn how to duplicate that feat, but he never could. He had to see how the pieces fit together before he could make sense of them. "Aram, find Grady and tell him to meet me as fast as he can, at the Traveling ground." That was what they had come to call the place where they arrived at the end of each jump, and departed from for the next. It was easier for the Asha'man to weave a gateway in a place already touched by one they had woven before.

ɛɹæm ɡeɪv wʌn ʃɔɹt, pɝpəsfəl nɑd, ðən wild ɪz ɡɹeɪ ən spɛd təwɔɹd kæmp, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd si ɑɹɡjəməns ən kwɛstʃənz ən dɪmænz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɑn ðə feɪsəz ɝaʊn hɪm. mɑɹlaɪn wɑz stɪl ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ hɪm, əz ðoʊ sʌɾənli nɑt kwaɪt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i wɑz, ən ɡælɛn wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə ɹeɪnz ɪn ɪz hænz, noʊ daʊt siɪŋ mæɾɝz tɝn aʊt bædli wʌtɛvɝ i dɪd, bʌt bɹəleɪn wɔɹ ə pɝtɝbd ɪkspɹɛʃən, əbdʒɛkʃənz vɪzəbəl ɪn əɹ aɪz, ən ənʊɹəz maʊθ hæd taɪɾənd tə ə θɪn laɪn. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ɪntɝʌptɪd, ænd, dɪfəɾənt fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ nɑt, ʃi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə vɛn əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ. ɑɹɡændə, hɪz feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹɛd, oʊpən ɪz maʊθ wɪð ðə klɪɹ ɪntɛntʃən ə ʃaʊɾɪŋ.

Aram gave one short, purposeful nod, then wheeled his gray and sped toward camp, but Perrin could see arguments and questions and demands gathering on the faces around him.
