Marline was still examining him, as though suddenly not quite sure what he was, and Gallenne was frowning at the reins in his hands, no doubt seeing matters turn out badly whatever he did, but Berelain wore a perturbed expression, objections visible in her eyes, and Annoura's mouth had tightened to a thin line. Aes Sedai disliked being interrupted, and, diffident for an Aes Sedai or not, she looked ready to vent her displeasure. Arganda, his face growing red, opened his mouth with the clear intention of shouting.

ɑɹɡændə hæd ʃaʊɾəd ɔfən sɪns ɪz kwin wɑz kɪdnæpt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn weɪɾɪŋ tə lɪsən.

Arganda had shouted often since his queen was kidnapped. There was no point in waiting to listen.

dɪɡɪŋ ɪn ɪz hilz, pɛɹɪn sɛn stɛpɝ lʌnʒɪŋ θɹu ðə laɪn ʌv wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, hɛɾɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə ʃɪɹd tʃɹiz. nɑɾ əɾ ə ɹʌn, bʌt nɑt dɔdlɪŋ, iðɝ - ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt θɹu ðə taʊɝɪŋ fɔɹəsts, hænz taɪɾ ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz ən aɪz ɔlɹɛɾi sɝtʃɪŋ ðə dæpəld ɡlum fəɹ ɡɹeɪɾi. ɛlaɪəs fɑloʊɾ ɑn ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i hæd noʊ ɹum ɪn ɪm fəɹ ənʌðɝ aʊns ə fɪɹ, jɛɾ ɛlaɪəs' saɪləns meɪd ðə weɪt ɡɹoʊ. ði ʌðɝ mæn nɛvɝ sɔ ən ɑbstəkəl wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ə weɪ ɝaʊnd. hɪz saɪləns ʃaʊɾəd ʌv ɪmpæsəbəl maʊntənz. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ, ðoʊ. wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə smuð stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp, pɛɹɪn wɔk stɛpɝ bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu ðə slæntɪŋ bɑɹz ə laɪt, ɝaʊn ðə tɑpəl tʃɹiz ən bɪtwin ðə stændɪŋ wʌnz, əneɪbəl tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf stɑp. hi hæd tə kip muvɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ. hɪz maɪn dɑɹɾɪd laɪk ə keɪdʒd ɹæt.

Digging in his heels, Perrin sent Stepper lunging through the line of Winged Guards, heading back toward the sheared trees. Not at a run, but not dawdling, either - a quick trot through the towering forests, hands tight on the reins and eyes already searching the dappled gloom for Grady. Elyas followed on his gelding without a word. Perrin had been sure he had no room in him for another ounce of fear, yet Elyas' silence made the weight grow. The other man never saw an obstacle without seeing a way around. His silence shouted of impassable mountains. There had to be a way, though. When they reached the smooth stone outcrop, Perrin walked Stepper back and forth through the slanting bars of light, around the toppled trees and between the standing ones, unable to make himself stop. He had to keep moving. There had to be a way. His mind darted like a caged rat.

ɛlaɪəs dɪsmaʊntɪd tə skwɑɾ ən fɹaʊn ət ðə slaɪst stoʊn, peɪ ɪŋ lɪɾəl hid tə hɪz ɡɛldɪŋ tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə ɹeɪnz ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bæk əweɪ. bɪsaɪd ðə stoʊn, ðə θɪk tʃɹʌŋk ʌv ə paɪn ðət hæd stʊɾ ə ɡʊd fɪfti peɪsɪz tɔl wɑz pɹɑpt ʌp ət wʌn ɛn baɪ ðə splɪntɝd ɹɪmeɪnz ʌv ɪts stʌmp, haɪ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs cʊɾə wɔk bɪniθ ðə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋk əpɹaɪt. bɹɪljən ɹeɪz ə sʌnlaɪt pɪɹsɪŋ ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi ɛlswɛɹ sim tə dipən ðə ʃædoʊ tə nɪɹ blæknəs ɝaʊn ðə tʃɹæk-mɑɹkt aʊtkɹɑp bʌt ðət tʃɹ blɛɾ ɪm noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɪt dɪd pɛɹɪn. hɪz noʊz ɹɪŋkəld ət ðə bɝnt-sʌlfɝ smɛl ðət stɪl hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. "aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kɑt ðɪs stɪŋk ɑn ðə weɪ hɪɹ. aɪ ɪkspɛk juɾ əv mɛnʃən ðɪs ɪf jə dɪdn əv θɪŋz ɑn jəɹ maɪnd. ə bɪɡ pæk. bɪɡɝ ðən ɛni θɪŋ aɪv ɛvɝ sin əɹ hɝɾ ʌv."

Elyas dismounted to squat and frown at the sliced stone, pay ing little heed to his gelding tugging at the reins and trying to back away. Beside the stone, the thick trunk of a pine that had stood a good fifty paces tall was propped up at one end by the splintered remains of its stump, high enough that Elyas could have walked beneath the tree trunk upright. Brilliant rays of sunlight piercing the forest canopy elsewhere seemed to deepen the shadow to near blackness around the track-marked outcrop but that trou bled him no more than it did Perrin. His nose wrinkled at the burnt-sulphur smell that still hung in the air. "I thought I caught this stink on the way here. I expect you'd have mentioned this if you didn't have things on your mind. A big pack. Bigger than any thing I've ever seen or heard of."

"ðæts wʌt mɑsʊɝi sɛd," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. wʌt wɑz kipɪŋ ɡɹeɪɾi? haʊ mɛni pipəl wɝ ðəɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ? ðət wɑz ðə saɪz ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp. "ʃi sɛd ʃiz kɹɔs ðə pæðz ə sɛvən pæks, ən ðɪs ɪzənt wʌn ʃiz sin bɪfɔɹ." "sɛvən," ɛlaɪəs mɝmɝɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ əv tə ɡoʊ səm tə də ðæt. moʊs teɪlz ə dɑɹkhaʊnz ɑɹ dʒʌs pipəl fɹaɪɾənd baɪ ðə dɑɹk." fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə tʃɹæks kɹɔsɪŋ ðə smuð stoʊn, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən sædnəs ɛntɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs wən i sɛd, "ðeɪ wɝ wʊlvz, wʌns. ðə soʊlz ʌv wʊlvz, ɛniweɪ, kɑɾ ən twɪstəd baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ. ðət wɑz ðə kɔɹ juz tə meɪk dɑɹkhaʊnz, ðə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz. aɪ θɪŋk ðæts waɪ ðə wʊlvz əv tə bi ət ðə læs bæɾəl. əɹ meɪbi dɑɹkhaʊnz wɝ meɪd kəz wʊlvz wɪl bi ðɛɹ, tə faɪt ðɛm. ðə pæɾɝn meɪks soʊvɹə leɪs lʊk laɪk ə pis ə stʃɹɪŋ, səmtaɪmz. ɛniweɪ, ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ, dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən meɪk aʊt, ən ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ bɪfɔɹ ðæt.

"That's what Masuri said," Perrin said absently. What was keeping Grady? How many people were there in Ebou Dar? That was the size of the Shaido camp. "She said she's crossed the paths of seven packs, and this isn't one she's seen before." "Seven," Elyas murmured in surprise. "Even an Aes Sedai would have to go some to do that. Most tales of Darkhounds are just people frightened by the dark." Frowning at the tracks crossing the smoothed stone, he shook his head, and sadness entered his voice when he said, "They were wolves, once. The souls of wolves, anyway, caught and twisted by the Shadow. That was the core used to make Darkhounds, the Shadowbrothers. I think that's why the wolves have to be at the Last Battle. Or maybe Darkhounds were made because wolves will be there, to fight them. The Pattern makes Sovarra lace look like a piece of string, sometimes. Anyway, it was a long time ago, during the Trolloc Wars as near as I can make out, and the War of the Shadow before that.

wʊlvz əv lɔŋ mɛmɹiz. wʌɾ ə wʊlf noʊz ɪz nɛvɝ ɹɪli fɝɡɑɾən waɪl ʌðɝ wʊlvz ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv. ðeɪ əvɔɪd tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt dɑɹkhaʊnz, ðoʊ, ən ðeɪ əvɔɪd dɑɹkhaʊnz, tu. ə hʌnʒɹəd wʊlvz kəd daɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl wʌn ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝ. wɝs, ɪf ðeɪ feɪl, ðə dɑɹkhaʊn kən it ðə soʊlz ə ðoʊz ðəɾ ɑɹən kwaɪt dɛd jɛt, ən ɪn ə jɪɹ əɹ soʊ, ðɛɹəd bi ə nu pæk ə ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz ðət dɪdn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɝ biɪŋ wʊlvz. aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɛniweɪ." pɛɹɪn ɹeɪn ɪn, ðoʊ hi ɪtʃt tə kip muvɪŋ. ʃæɾoʊbɹəðɝz. ðə wʊlvz' neɪm fəɹ dɑɹkhaʊnz hæd teɪkən ɑn ə nu ɡɹɪmnəs. "kæn ðeɪ iɾ ə mænz soʊl, ɛlaɪəs? seɪ ə mæn u kən tɔk tə wʊlvz?" ɛlaɪəs ʃɹʌɡd. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə pipəl kəd də wʌt ðeɪ dɪd, əz fɑɹ əz iðɝ mæn nu. ən ænsɝ tə ðət kwɛstʃən maɪt kʌm oʊnli ət ðə pɔɪn ə dɛθ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli ɹaɪt ðɛn, ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn wʊlvz, wʌns, ðeɪ mʌs bi ɪntɛlədʒən ɪnʌf tə ɹipɔɹt wʌt ðeɪ faʊnd. mɑsʊɝi hæɾ ɪmplaɪɾ əz mʌtʃ. fulɪʃnəs tə hoʊp ʌðɝwaɪz. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪd? haʊ lɔŋ dɪɾ i hæv tə fɹi feɪl?

Wolves have long memories. What a wolf knows is never really forgotten while other wolves remain alive. They avoid talking about Darkhounds, though, and they avoid Darkhounds, too. A hundred wolves could die trying to kill one Shadowbrother. Worse, if they fail, the Darkhound can eat the souls of those that aren't quite dead yet, and in a year or so, there'd be a new pack of Shadowbrothers that didn't remember ever being wolves. I hope they don't remember, anyway." Perrin reined in, though he itched to keep moving. Shadowbrothers. The wolves' name for Darkhounds had taken on a new grimness. "Can they eat a man's soul, Elyas? Say a man who can talk to wolves?" Elyas shrugged. Only a handful of people could do what they did, as far as either man knew. An answer to that question might come only at the point of death. More importantly right then, if they had been wolves, once, they must be intelligent enough to report what they found. Masuri had implied as much. Foolishness to hope otherwise. How long before they did? How long did he have to free Faile?

ðə saʊn ə hʊvz kɹʌntʃɪŋ ɪn snoʊ ənaʊnst ɹaɪɾɝz kʌmɪŋ, ən i hɝidli toʊld ɛlaɪəs ðət ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz hæd sɝkəl ðə kæmp, ðət ðeɪ wəd bi kæɹiɪŋ wɝɾ ə hɪm tə humɛvɝ ðeɪ ɹipɔɹɾəd tə.

The sound of hooves crunching in snow announced riders coming, and he hurriedly told Elyas that the Darkhounds had circled the camp, that they would be carrying word of him to whomever they reported to.

"aɪ wʊdnt wɝi oʊvɝmək, bɔɪ," ði oʊldɝ mæn ɹɪplaɪd, wɑtʃɪŋ wɛɹəli fəɹ saɪɾ ə ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ hɔɹsəz. muvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə stoʊn, hi bɪɡæn tə stʃɹɛtʃ, wɝkɪŋ mʌsəlz oʊvɝ-lɔŋ ɪn ðə sæɾəl. ɛlaɪəs wɑz tu kɛɹfəl tə bi kɑt stʌɾiɪŋ wʌt wəd bi swɑloʊɾ ɪn ʃædoʊz tə ʌðɝ aɪz.

"I wouldn't worry overmuch, boy," the older man replied, watching warily for sight of the oncoming horses. Moving away from the stone, he began to stretch, working muscles over-long in the saddle. Elyas was too careful to be caught studying what would be swallowed in shadows to other eyes.

"saʊnz laɪk ðəɹ hʌntɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ju. ðəl steɪ ɑn ðət tɪl ðeɪ faɪn ɪɾ ɪf ɪt teɪks ɔl jɪɹ. doʊnt wɝi. wɪl ɡɛt jəɹ waɪf aʊt bɪfɔɹ ðoʊz dɑɹkhaʊnz ɹipɔɹt jə wɝ hɪɹ.

"Sounds like they're hunting something more important than you. They'll stay on that till they find it if it takes all year. Don't worry. We'll get your wife out before those Darkhounds report you were here.

nɑt seɪɪŋ ɪɾəl bi izi, bʌt wɪl də ɪt." ðəɹ wɑz dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɪn ɪz vɔɪs, ən ɪn ɪz sɛnt, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ hoʊp. ɔlmoʊs nʌn əɾ ɔl, ɪn fækt. faɪɾɪŋ dɪspɛɹ, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛɾ ɪt ɹaɪz əɡɛn, pɛɹɪn ɹɪzumd wɔkɪŋ stɛpɝ əz bɹəleɪn ən əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd əpɪɹd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, wɪð mɑɹlaɪn əstʃɹaɪd bɪhaɪn ənʊɹə. əz sun əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dʒɹu ɹeɪn, ðə twaɪlaɪt-aɪd waɪz wʌn slɪd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ʃeɪkɪŋ daʊn əɹ θɪk skɝts tə kʌvɝ əɹ dɑɹk stɑkɪŋz. ənʌðɝ wʊmən maɪɾ əv əpɪɹd flʌstɝɾ oʊvɝ hævɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz ɪkspoʊzd, bʌt nɑt mɑɹlaɪn. ʃi wɑz mɪɹli stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ kloʊðz. ənʊɹə wɑz ðə wʌn u lʊkt əpsɛt, ə saʊɝ-feɪs dɪsɡɹʌntəlmən ðət meɪɾ əɹ noʊz sim mɔɹ laɪk ə bik. ʃi kɛp saɪlənt, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ wɑz sɛt tə baɪt. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn sɝɾən əɹ ɔfɝ tə nəɡoʊʃieɪt wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wəd bi æksɛptɪd, ɪspɛʃli wɪð bɹəleɪn səpɔɹɾɪŋ ən mɑɹlaɪn simɪŋli nutʃɹəl ət wɝst. ɡɹeɪz wɝ nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɝz ən miɾieɪtɝz, ədʒuɾɪkeɪtɝz ən tʃɹiɾi meɪkɝz. ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn əɹ moʊɾəveɪʃən.

Not saying it'll be easy, but we'll do it." There was determination in his voice, and in his scent, but not much hope. Almost none at all, in fact. Fighting despair, refusing to let it rise again, Perrin resumed walking Stepper as Berelain and her bodyguard appeared through the trees, with Marline astride behind Annoura. As soon as the Aes Sedai drew rein, the twilight-eyed Wise One slid to the ground, shaking down her thick skirts to cover her dark stockings. Another woman might have appeared flustered over having her legs exposed, but not Marline. She was merely straightening her clothes. Annoura was the one who looked upset, a sour-faced disgruntlement that made her nose seem more like a beak. She kept silent, but her mouth was set to bite. She must have been certain her offer to negotiate with the Shaido would be accepted, especially with Berelain supporting and Marline seemingly neutral at worst. Grays were negotiators and mediators, adjudicators and treaty makers. That might have been her motivation.

wʌɾ ɛls kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn? ə pɹɑbləm ðəɾ i hæd tə sɛɾ əsaɪd waɪl kipɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn maɪnd. hi hæd tə teɪk ɪndə əkaʊn ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð fɹiɪŋ feɪl, bʌt ðə pɹɑbləm i hæd tə sɑlv leɪ fɔɹɾi maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθist. waɪl ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz fɔɹm ðɛɹ pɹətɛktɪv sɝkəl əmʌŋ ðə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹiz ɝaʊn ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, bɹəleɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ beɪ əlɔŋsaɪd stɛpɝ ən peɪs hɪm, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ pɛɹɪn ɪn tɔk, tə ɪntaɪs ɪm wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wʊɾən. ʃi smɛld ənsɝɾən, daʊtfəl ə hɪz dɪsɪʒən. meɪbi ʃi hoʊp tə tɔk ɪm ɪndə ətɛmptɪŋ ðə ɹænsəm. hi kɛp stɛpɝ muvɪŋ ən ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən. tə meɪk ðəɾ ətɛmpt wɑz tə ɡæmbəl ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn wʌn tɔs ə ðə daɪs. hi kəd nɑt ɡæmbəl wɪð feɪl əz ðə steɪk. məθɑɾəkəl əz wɝkɪŋ əɾ ə fɔɹdʒ, ðət wɑz ðə weɪ. laɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz taɪɝd. hi foʊldəd hɪmsɛlf ɪn taɪɾɝ ɝaʊn ɪz æŋɡɝ, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə hit fəɹ ɛnɝdʒi.

What else could it have been? A problem that he had to set aside while keeping it in mind. He had to take into account anything that might interfere with freeing Faile, but the problem he had to solve lay forty miles to the northeast. While the Winged Guards formed their protective circle among the towering trees around the Traveling ground, Berelain brought her bay alongside Stepper and paced him, trying to engage Perrin in talk, to entice him with the rest of the woodhen. She smelled uncertain, doubtful of his decision. Maybe she hoped to talk him into attempting the ransom. He kept Stepper moving and refused to listen. To make that attempt was to gamble everything on one toss of the dice. He could not gamble with Faile as the stake. Methodical as working at a forge, that was the way. Light, but he was tired. He folded himself in tighter around his anger, embracing the heat for energy.

ɡælɛn ən ɑɹɡændə ɝaɪvd ʃɔɹtli æftɝ bɹəleɪn, wɪð ə dʌbəl kɑləm ʌv ɡildænɪn lænsɝz ɪn bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ən bɹaɪt kɑnɪkəl hɛlməts u ɪntɝspɝs ðɛmsɛlvz əmʌŋ ðə minɝz bɪtwin ðə tʃɹiz. ə tʃɹeɪs ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən ɛntɝɪŋ əɹ sɛnt, bɹəleɪn lɛf pɛɹɪn ən ɹoʊd tə ɡælɛn. ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm sæt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ni-tə-ni, ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn bɛndɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə lɪsən tə wʌt bɹəleɪn hæd tə seɪ. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz loʊ, bʌt pɛɹɪn nu ðɛɹ sʌbʒɪkt, ət list ɪn pɑɹt. naʊ ən ðən wʌn ə ðɛm ɡlænst əɾ ɪm əz i wɔk stɛpɝ bæk ən fɔɹθ, bæk ən fɔɹθ. ɑɹɡændə plæntəɾ ɪz ɹoʊn ɪn wʌn spɑɾ ən stɛɹd saʊθ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, stɪl əz ə stætʃu jɛt ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃəns əz ə faɪɝ ɹeɪɾieɪtəd hit. hi wɑz ðə pɪktʃɝ ʌv ə soʊlʒɝ, wɪð ɪz plumz ən ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ɪz sɪlvɝɾ ɑɹmɝ, hɪz feɪs əz hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn, bʌɾ i smɛld ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə pænɪk. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd haʊ hi hɪmsɛlf smɛld. jə kəd nɛvɝ kætʃ jəɹ oʊn sɛn ənlɛs jə wɝ ɪn ə kloʊz speɪs. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i smɛld ə pænɪk, dʒʌs fɪɹ ən æŋɡɝ. ɔl wəd bi wɛl wʌns i hæd feɪl bæk. ɔl wəd bi wɛl, ðɛn. bæk ən fɔɹθ, bæk ən fɔɹθ.

Gallenne and Arganda arrived shortly after Berelain, with a double column of Ghealdanin lancers in burnished breastplates and bright conical helmets who interspersed themselves among the Mayeners between the trees. A trace of irritation entering her scent, Berelain left Perrin and rode to Gallenne. The pair of them sat their horses knee-to-knee, the one-eyed man bending his head to listen to what Berelain had to say. Her voice was low, but Perrin knew their subject, at least in part. Now and then one of them glanced at him as he walked Stepper back and forth, back and forth. Arganda planted his roan in one spot and stared south through the trees toward the camp, still as a statue yet radiating impatience as a fire radiated heat. He was the picture of a soldier, with his plumes and his sword and his silvered armor, his face as hard as stone, but he smelled on the brink of panic. Perrin wondered how he himself smelled. You could never catch your own scent unless you were in a closed space. He did not think he smelled of panic, just fear and anger. All would be well once he had Faile back. All would be well, then. Back and forth, back and forth.

ət læst ɛɹæm əpɪɹd, wɪð ə jɔnɪŋ dʒɝ ɡɹeɪɾi ɑn ə dɑɹk beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ, dɑɹk ɪnʌf ðət ðə waɪt stʃɹaɪp ɑn ɪts noʊz meɪɾ ɪt sim ɔlmoʊst ə blæk. dænɪl ən ə dʌzən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, spɪɹz ən hælbɝdz əbændən fəɹ ðə moʊmən ɪn feɪvɝ ə ðɛɹ lɔŋboʊz, ɹoʊd kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, bʌt nɑt tu kloʊz. ə stɑki fɛloʊ wɪð ə wɛðɝd feɪs ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ʃoʊ kɹisɪz, ðoʊ hi wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ə hɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz jɛt, ɡɹeɪɾi lʊk laɪk ə slipi fɑɹmɝ dɪspaɪɾ ə ðə lɔŋ-haɪk sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst ən ɪz blæk koʊt wɪð ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹd pɪn ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ, bʌɾ i hæd lɛf ðə fɑɹm bɪhaɪn fɝɛvɝ, ən dænɪl ən ði ʌðɝz ɔlweɪz ɡeɪv ɪm ɹum. ðeɪ ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ɹum, tu, hæŋɪŋ bæk ən piɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd, səmtaɪmz dɑɹɾɪŋ kwɪk, ɪmbɛɹəs lʊks əɾ ɪm əɹ bɹəleɪn. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. ɔl wəd bi wɛl. ɛɹæm tʃɹaɪd tə lid ɡɹeɪɾi tə pɛɹɪn, bʌt ði æʃəmən nu waɪ hi hæd bɪn sʌmənd. wɪð ə saɪ, hi klaɪm daʊn bɪsaɪɾ ɛlaɪəs, hu skwɑɾɪd ɪn ə pætʃ ə sʌnlaɪt tə mɑɹk ə mæp ɪn ðə snoʊ wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝ ən spik ə dɪstəns ən dɝɛkʃən, dɪskɹaɪbɪŋ ðə pleɪs i wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ ɪn dɪteɪl, ə klɪɹɪŋ ɑn ə sloʊp ðət feɪst ɔlmoʊst saʊθ, wɪð ðə ɹɪdʒ əbʌv nɑtʃt ɪn θɹi pleɪsəz.

At last Aram appeared, with a yawning Jur Grady on a dark bay gelding, dark enough that the white stripe on its nose made it seem almost a black. Dannil and a dozen Two Rivers men, spears and halberds abandoned for the moment in favor of their longbows, rode close behind, but not too close. A stocky fellow with a weathered face already beginning to show creases, though he was short of his middle years yet, Grady looked like a sleepy farmer despite of the long-hiked sword at his waist and his black coat with the silver sword pin on the high collar, but he had left the farm behind forever, and Dannil and the others always gave him room. They gave Perrin room, too, hanging back and peering at the ground, sometimes darting quick, embarrassed looks at him or Berelain. It did not matter. All would be well. Aram tried to lead Grady to Perrin, but the Asha'man knew why he had been summoned. With a sigh, he climbed down beside Elyas, who squatted in a patch of sunlight to mark a map in the snow with his finger and speak of distance and direction, describing the place he wanted to go in detail, a clearing on a slope that faced almost south, with the ridge above notched in three places.

dɪstəns ən dɝɛkʃən wɝ ɪnʌf, ɪf ðə dɪstəns ən dɝɛkʃən wɝ pɹɪsaɪs, bʌt ðə bɛɾɝ ðə pɪktʃɝ ɪn ən æʃəmənz maɪnd, ðə kloʊsɝ i kəd kʌm tə ən ɪɡzæk spɑt.

Distance and direction were enough, if the distance and direction were precise, but the better the picture in an Asha'man's mind, the closer he could come to an exact spot.

"ðɛɹz noʊ mɑɹdʒən fəɹ ɛɹɝ hɪɹ, bɔɪ." ɛlaɪəsəz aɪz sim tə bɹaɪɾən wɪð ɪntɛnsəɾi.

"There's no margin for error here, boy." Elyas's eyes seemed to brighten with intensity.

wʌtɛvɝ ʌðɝz θɔɾ ʌv æʃəmən, ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd hɪm. "ðɛɹz lɑts ə ɹɪdʒəz ɪn ðət kʌntʃɹi, ən ðə meɪn kæmp ɪz oʊnli ə maɪl əɹ soʊ ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðɪs wʌn. ðɛɹəl bi sɛntʃɹiz, lɪɾəl pɑɹɾiz ðət kæmp ɪn ə dɪfɹən pleɪs ɛvɹi naɪt, meɪbi lɛs ðən tu maɪlz ði ʌðɝ weɪ. jə pʊɾ əs aʊɾ ɔf baɪ mʌtʃ, ən wɪl bi sin fəɹ ʃʊɹ." ɡɹeɪɾi mɛt ðət stɛɹ, ənblɪŋkɪŋ. ðən i nɑɾəd ən skɹʌb stʌbi ɹɪŋɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ. hi lʊkt əz wɪɹi əz ɛlaɪəs. əz boʊn-taɪɝɾ əz pɛɹɪn fɛlt. meɪkɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz, hoʊldɪŋ əm oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ θaʊzənz ə pipəl ən hɔɹsəz tə pæs θɹu, wɑz wɛɹɪŋ wɝk. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛstəɾ ɪnʌf?" pɛɹɪn æsk hɪm. taɪɝd mɛn meɪd mɪsteɪks, ən mɪsteɪks wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd bi dɛdli. "ʃʊɾ aɪ sɛn fəɹ nild?" ɡɹeɪɾi stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪm blɝəli, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "peɪdʒɝz noʊ mɔɹ ɹɛstəd ðən mi. lɛs, meɪbi. aɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən i ɪz, ə bɪt. bɛɾɝ ɪf aɪ də ɪt." hi tɝn tə feɪs nɔɹθist, ən wɪð noʊ mɔɹ wɔɹnɪŋ, ə vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə sɪlvɝ-blu əpɪɹd bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɹækmɑɹk stoʊn. ənʊɹə dʒɝkt əɹ mɛɹ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ wɪð ə laʊd ɡæsp əz ðə laɪn ə laɪt waɪɾənd ɪndə ən oʊpənɪŋ, ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ ðət ʃoʊɾ ə sʌnlɪt klɪɹɪŋ ɑn stip ɡɹaʊn əmʌŋ tʃɹiz mʌtʃ smɔlɝ ðən ðoʊz ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. ði ɔlɹɛɾi splɪntɝd paɪn ʃɪvɝɾ əz ɪt lɔst ənʌðɝ θɪn slaɪs, ɡɹoʊnd, ən kəlæps ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ wɪð ə snoʊ-mʌfəl kɹæʃ ðət meɪd ðə hɔɹsəz snɔɹɾ ən dæns. ənʊɹə ɡlɛɹɾ ət ði æʃəmən, hɝ feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɑɹk, bʌt ɡɹeɪɾi dʒʌs blɪŋkt ən sɛd, "dʌz ðət lʊk laɪk ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs?" ɛlaɪəs ədʒʌstəɾ ɪz hæt bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ.

Whatever others thought of Asha'man, they never intimidated him. "There's lots of ridges in that country, and the main camp is only a mile or so the other side of this one. There'll be sentries, little parties that camp in a different place every night, maybe less than two miles the other way. You put us out off by much, and we'll be seen for sure." Grady met that stare, unblinking. Then he nodded and scrubbed stubby ringers through his hair, drawing a deep breath. He looked as weary as Elyas. As bone-tired as Perrin felt. Making gateways, holding them open long enough for thousands of people and horses to pass through, was wearing work. "Are you rested enough?" Perrin asked him. Tired men made mistakes, and mistakes with the One Power could be deadly. "Should I send for Neald?" Grady stared up at him blearily, then shook his head. "Pager's no more rested than me. Less, maybe. I'm stronger than he is, a bit. Better if I do it." He turned to face northeast, and with no more warning, a vertical slash of silver-blue appeared beside the trackmarked stone. Annoura jerked her mare out of the way with a loud gasp as the line of light widened into an opening, a hole in the air that showed a sunlit clearing on steep ground among trees much smaller than those around Perrin and the others. The already splintered pine shivered as it lost another thin slice, groaned, and collapsed the rest of the way with a snow-muffled crash that made the horses snort and dance. Annoura glared at the Asha'man, her face growing dark, but Grady just blinked and said, "Does that look like the right place?" Elyas adjusted his hat before nodding.

ðət nɑd wɑz ɔl pɛɹɪn weɪɾəd fɔɹ. hi dʌkt ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹoʊd stɛpɝ θɹu ɪndə snoʊ ðət wɑz oʊvɝ ðə dʌnz fɛtlɑks. ɪt wɑz ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ, bʌt ðə skaɪ fʊl ʌv waɪt klaʊdz oʊvɝhɛd meɪɾ ɪt sim væsli oʊpən æftɝ ðə fɔɹəs bɪhaɪnd. ðə laɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs blaɪndɪŋ kəmpɛɹd tə ðə fɔɹəst, ðoʊ ðə sʌn wɑz stɪl hɪɾən baɪ ðə tʃɹi-kʌvɝd ɹɪdʒ əbʌv. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp leɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðət ɹɪdʒ. hi stɛɹd təwɔɹd ðə haɪt jɝnɪŋli. ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə steɪ wɛɹ i wɑz ɹæðɝ ðən ɹeɪs əhɛd tə faɪnəli si wɛɹ feɪl wɑz. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf tɝn stɛpɝ tə feɪs ðə ɡeɪtweɪ əz mɑɹlaɪn keɪm aʊt.

That nod was all Perrin waited for. He ducked his head and rode Stepper through into snow that was over the dun's fetlocks. It was a small clearing, but the sky full of white clouds overhead made it seem vastly open after the forest behind. The light was almost blinding compared to the forest, though the sun was still hidden by the tree-covered ridge above. The Shaido camp lay on the other side of that ridge. He stared toward the height yearningly. It was all he could do to stay where he was rather than race ahead to finally see where Faile was. He made himself turn Stepper to face the gateway as Marline came out.

stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ hɪm, hɑɹdli teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz əweɪ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pleɪs əɹ fiɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ wɪθaʊt tʃɹɪpɪŋ, ʃi muv tə wʌn saɪd tə lɛɾ ɛɹæm ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɹaɪd θɹu. əkʌstəm tə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪf nɑt tə æʃəmən baɪ naʊ, ðeɪ bɛɹli bɛn ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪnʌf tə klɪɹ ðə tɑp ə ði oʊpənɪŋ, ən oʊnli ðə tɔlɪs dɪɾ ivən ðæt. ɪt stʃɹʌk pɛɹɪn ðət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðə fɝst wʌn ʌv ɡɹeɪɾiz meɪk ðəɾ i hæd pæs θɹu. hi hæd hæd tə dɪsmaʊnt, ðɛn. ɪt wɑz ə veɪɡ θɔt, noʊ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ə flaɪ bʌzɪŋ. ɛɹæm ɹoʊd stʃɹeɪt tə pɛɹɪn, taɪt-feɪst ən smɛlɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃən ən iɡɝ tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, ən wʌns dænɪl ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, klaɪmɪŋ daʊn ən kɑmli fɪɾɪŋ æɹoʊz tə baʊz waɪl ðeɪ wɑtʃt ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz, ɡælɛn əpɪɹd, piɹɪŋ ɡɹɪmli ət ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn əm əz ðoʊ hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ɛnəmi tə kʌm dæʃɪŋ aʊt, fɑloʊd baɪ hæf ə dʌzən minɝz u hæd tə loʊɝ ðɛɹ ɹɛd-stʃɹimɝd lænsɪz tə kɹaʊd θɹu æftɝ hɪm.

Still studying him, hardly taking her eyes away long enough to place her feet in the snow without tripping, she moved to one side to let Aram and the Two Rivers men ride through. Accustomed to Traveling if not to Asha'man by now, they barely bent their heads enough to clear the top of the opening, and only the tallest did even that. It struck Perrin that the gateway was larger than the first one of Grady's make that he had passed through. He had had to dismount, then. It was a vague thought, no more important than a fly buzzing. Aram rode straight to Perrin, tight-faced and smelling impatient and eager to be going on, and once Dannil and the others were out of the way, climbing down and calmly fitting arrows to bows while they watched the surrounding trees, Gallenne appeared, peering grimly at the trees around them as though he expected an enemy to come dashing out, followed by half a dozen Mayeners who had to lower their red-streamered lances to crowd through after him.

ə lɔŋ pɔz pæst wɪð ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɛmpti, bʌt dʒʌst wən pɛɹɪn hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɡoʊ bæk ən si wʌt wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɛlaɪəs ʌp, ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn lɛɾ ɪz hɔɹs aʊt, wɪð ɑɹɡændə ən sɪks ɡildænɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ əɾ ɪz hilz, dɪskəntɛn kɑɹvd ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ðɛɹ ʃaɪnɪŋ hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts wɝ noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin, ən ðeɪ skaʊld əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd bɪn meɪd tə liv ɔf ðɛɹ bɹitʃɪz.

A long pause passed with the gateway empty, but just when Perrin had decided to go back and see what was holding Elyas up, the bearded man led his horse out, with Arganda and six Ghealdanin riding at his heels, discontent carved on their faces. Their shining helmets and breastplates were nowhere to be seen, and they scowled as though they had been made to leave off their breeches.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf. ʌv kɔɹs. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp wɑz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðɪs ɹɪdʒ, ən soʊ wɑz ðə sʌn. ðət ɡlimɪŋ ɑɹmɝ wʊɾə bɪn laɪk mɪɹɝz. hi ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ə ðæt. hi wɑz stɪl lɛɾɪŋ fɪɹ ɡoʊɾ ɪm ɪndə ɪmpeɪʃəns ən klaʊɾ ɪz θɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæd tə bi klɪɹhɛɾɪd, naʊ mɔɹ ðən ɛvɝ. ðə dɪteɪl i mɪs naʊ kəd kɪl ɪm ən liv feɪl ɪn ʃeɪɾoʊ hænz. ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə seɪ ðəɾ i hæd tə lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv fɪɹ ðən tə də ɪt, ðoʊ. haʊ kəɾ i nɑt bi əfɹeɪd fəɹ feɪl? ɪt hæd tə bi mænədʒd, bʌt haʊ?

Perrin nodded to himself. Of course. The Shaido camp was on the other side of this ridge, and so was the sun. That gleaming armor would have been like mirrors. He should have thought of that. He was still letting fear goad him into impatience and cloud his thinking. He had to be clearheaded, now more than ever. The detail he missed now could kill him and leave Faile in Shaido hands. It was easier to say that he had to let go of fear than to do it, though. How could he not be afraid for Faile? It had to be managed, but how?

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ənʊɹə ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪɾi, hu wɑz liɾɪŋ ɪz dɑɹk beɪ. dʒʌst əz ɛvɹi taɪm i hæd sin əɹ pæs θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ʃi leɪ əz flæɾ ɑn əɹ mɛɹ əz əɹ sæɾəlz haɪ pɑməl wəɾ əlaʊ, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət ði oʊpənɪŋ ðət hæd bɪn meɪd wɪð ðə teɪntɪd meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ, ən əz sun əz ʃi wɑz klɪɹ ʌv ɪt, ʃi ɝdʒd əɹ hɔɹs əz fɑɹ ʌp ðə sloʊp əz ʃi kəd wɪθaʊɾ ɛntɝɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz. ɡɹeɪɾi lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ snæp ʃʌt, livɪŋ ðə pɝpəl æftɝɪmɪdʒ ʌv ə vɝɾɪkəl bɑɹ ɪn pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ən ənʊɹə flɪntʃt ən lʊkt əweɪ, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət mɑɹlaɪn, ət pɛɹɪn. ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi wʊɾə sɛd ʃi wɑz sɪmɝɪŋ ɪn ə sʌlən fjʊɹi. bɹəleɪn mʌst əv toʊld əɹ tə kʌm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt bɹəleɪn ʃi bleɪm fəɹ əɹ hævɪŋ tə bi ðɛɹ.

To his surprise, Annoura rode through the gateway just ahead of Grady, who was leading his dark bay. Just as every time he had seen her pass through a gateway, she lay as flat on her mare as her saddle's high pommel would allow, grimacing at the opening that had been made with the tainted male half of the Power, and as soon as she was clear of it, she urged her horse as far up the slope as she could without entering the trees. Grady let the gateway snap shut, leaving the purple afterimage of a vertical bar in Perrin's eyes, and Annoura flinched and looked away, glaring at Marline, at Perrin. If she had been anyone other than an Aes Sedai, he would have said she was simmering in a sullen fury. Berelain must have told her to come, but it was not Berelain she blamed for her having to be there.

"fɹʌm hɪɹ, wi ɡoʊ əfʊt," ɛlaɪəs ənaʊnst ɪn ə kwaɪət vɔɪs ðət bɛɹli kæɹiɾ oʊvɝ ði əkeɪʒənəl stæmp ʌv ə hɔɹsəz huf. hi hæd sɛd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ kɛɹləs ən hæd noʊ sɛntʃɹiz, əɹ ɔlmoʊs nʌn, bʌɾ i spoʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi wɪðɪn twɛnti peɪsɪz. "ə mæn ɑn ə hɔɹs stænz aʊt. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɑɹən blaɪnd, dʒʌs blaɪn fəɹ il, wɪtʃ minz ðeɪ si twaɪs əz ʃɑɹp əz ɛni ʌv ju, soʊ doʊnt ɡoʊ skaɪlaɪnɪŋ jʊɹsɛlvz wən wi ɹitʃ ðə kɹɛst. ən tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə meɪk ɛni mɔɹ nɔɪz ðən jə kən hɛlp.

"From here, we go afoot," Elyas announced in a quiet voice that barely carried over the occasional stamp of a horse's hoof. He had said the Shaido were careless and had no sentries, or almost none, but he spoke as if they could be within twenty paces. "A man on a horse stands out. The Shaido aren't blind, just blind for Aiel, which means they see twice as sharp as any of you, so don't go skylining yourselves when we reach the crest. And try not to make any more noise than you can help.

ðeɪ ɑɹən dɛf, iðɝ. ðəl faɪn əɹ tʃɹæks, ɪvɛntʃəwəli - kæn də mʌtʃ əbaʊt ðəɾ ɪn snoʊ - bʌt wi kæn lɛɾ əm noʊ wi wɝ hɪɹ əntɪl æftɝ wɝ ɡɔn." ɔlɹɛɾi saʊɝ oʊvɝ biɪŋ ʃɔɹn ə hɪz ɑɹmɝ ən plumz, ɑɹɡændə bɪɡæn tə ɑɹɡju əbaʊɾ ɛlaɪəs ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. nɑt biɪŋ ə kəmplit ful, hi dɪɾ ɪɾ ɪn ə kwaɪət vɔɪs ðət wəd nɑt kæɹi, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ə soʊlʒɝ sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə fɪftin, hi hæd kəmændəd soʊlʒɝz faɪɾɪŋ waɪtkloʊks, ɔltɑɹənz ən ɑmɑdɪʃənz, ən əz i wɑz fɑn ə pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt, hi hæd fɔɾ ɪn ði il wɔɹ ən lɪv θɹu ðə blʌd snoʊ, ət tɑɹ vəlɑn. hi nu əbaʊɾ il, ən i dɪd nɑt niɾ ən ənbɑɹbɝd wʊdzmən tə tɛl ɪm haʊ tə pʊɾ ɪz buts ɑn. pɛɹɪn lɛɾ ɪt pæs, sɪns ðə mæn dɪɾ ɪz kəmpleɪnɪŋ ɪn bɪtwin tɛlɪŋ ɔf tu mɛn tə hoʊl ðə hɔɹsəz. hi ɹɪli wɑz nɑɾ ə ful, dʒʌst əfɹeɪd fəɹ ɪz kwin. ɡælɛn lɛft ɔl ə hɪz mɛn bɪhaɪnd, mʌɾɝɪŋ ðət lænsɝz wɝ wɝs ðən jusləs ɔf ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ən wəd pɹɑbli bɹeɪk ðɛɹ nɛks ɪf i meɪɾ əm wɔk ɛni dɪstəns. hi wɑz noʊ ful, iðɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd si ðə blæk saɪd fɝst. ɛlaɪəs tʊk ðə lɛd, ən pɛɹɪn weɪɾəd oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹænsfɝ ðə θɪk bɹæs-baʊn tub ə hɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs fɹəm stɛpɝz sæɾəlbæɡz tə hɪz koʊt pɑkət bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ.

They aren't deaf, either. They'll find our tracks, eventually - can't do much about that in snow - but we can't let them know we were here until after we're gone." Already sour over being shorn of his armor and plumes, Arganda began to argue about Elyas giving orders. Not being a complete fool, he did it in a quiet voice that would not carry, but he had been a soldier since the age of fifteen, he had commanded soldiers fighting Whitecloaks, Altarans and Amadicians, and as he was fond of pointing out, he had fought in the Aiel War and lived through the Blood Snow, at Tar Valon. He knew about Aiel, and he did not need an unbarbered woodsman to tell him how to put his boots on. Perrin let it pass, since the man did his complaining in between telling off two men to hold the horses. He really was not a fool, just afraid for his queen. Gallenne left all of his men behind, muttering that lancers were worse than useless off their horses and would probably break their necks if he made them walk any distance. He was no fool, either, but he did see the black side first. Elyas took the lead, and Perrin waited only long enough to transfer the thick brass-bound tube of his looking glass from Stepper's saddlebags to his coat pocket before following.

ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ ɡɹu ɪn klʌmps bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz, wɪtʃ wɝ moʊsli paɪn ən fɝ, wɪð klʌstɝz ʌv ʌðɝz ðət wɝ wɪntɝ-ɡɹeɪ ən lifləs, ən ðə tɝeɪn, noʊ stipɝ ðən ðə sæn hɪlz bæk hoʊm, ɪf mɔɹ ɹɑki, pɹizɛntəd noʊ pɹɑbləmz fəɹ dænɪl ən ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, hu ɡɑstɪɾ ʌp ðə sloʊp wɪð æɹoʊz nɑkt ən aɪz wɑtʃfəl, ɔlmoʊst əz saɪlən əz ðə mɪst ə ðɛɹ bɹɛθ. ɛɹæm, noʊ stʃɹeɪnʒɝ tə ðə wʊdz hɪmsɛlf, steɪd kloʊs tə pɛɹɪn wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ aʊt. wʌns i stɑɹɾəd tə tʃɑp ə tæŋɡəl ə θɪk bɹaʊn vaɪnz aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ əntɪl pɛɹɪn stɑpt ɪm wɪð ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, jɛɾ i meɪd lɪɾəl mɔɹ nɔɪz ðən pɛɹɪn, ðə feɪn kɹʌntʃ ə buts ɪn snoʊ. ɪt wɑz noʊ ʃɑk ðət mɑɹlaɪn muv θɹu ðə tʃɹiz əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp ɪn ə fɔɹəst ɪnstɛɾ ə ði il weɪst, wɛɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd bi kɔld ə tʃɹi wɑz ɹɛɹ ən snoʊ ənhɝɾ ʌv, ðoʊ ɪt sim ðəɾ ɔl ə hɝ nɛkləsɪz ən bɹeɪslɪts ʃʊɾə meɪd səm klæɾɝ əz ðeɪ swʌŋ, bʌɾ ənʊɹə klaɪmd wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz lɪɾəl ɛfɝt, flaʊndɝɪŋ ə lɪɾəl wɪð əɹ skɝts bʌt dɛfli əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə ʃɑɹp θɔɹnz ə dɛd kætsklɔ ən weɪt-ə-mɪnət vaɪnz. ɛɛs sədaɪ juʒəwəli faʊn ə weɪ tə sɝpɹaɪz ju. ʃi mænədʒ tə kip ə wɛɹi aɪ ɑn ɡɹeɪɾi, tu, ðoʊ ði æʃəmən əpɪɹd tə bi foʊkəst ɑn pʊɾɪŋ wʌn fʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ. səmtaɪmz i saɪd hɛvəli ən pɔz fəɹ ə mɪnət, fɹaʊnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kɹɛst əhɛd, bʌt sʌmhaʊ hi nɛvɝ fɛl bɪhaɪnd. ɡælɛn ən ɑɹɡændə wɝ nɑt jʌŋ mɛn, nɔɹ əkʌstəm tə wɔkɪŋ wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd ɹaɪd, ən ðɛɹ bɹiðɪŋ bɪɡæn tə ɡɹoʊ hɛviɝ əz ðeɪ əsɛndəd, səmtaɪmz pʊlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi, bʌt ðeɪ wɑtʃt wʌn ənʌðɝ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ dɪd ðə ɡɹaʊnd, itʃ ənwɪlɪŋ tə lɛt ði ʌðɝ aʊtdu hɪm.

The underbrush grew in clumps beneath the trees, which were mostly pine and fir, with clusters of others that were winter-gray and leafless, and the terrain, no steeper than the Sand Hills back home, if more rocky, presented no problems for Dannil and the other Two Rivers men, who ghosted up the slope with arrows nocked and eyes watchful, almost as silent as the mist of their breath. Aram, no stranger to the woods himself, stayed close to Perrin with his sword out. Once he started to chop a tangle of thick brown vines out of his way until Perrin stopped him with a hand on his arm, yet he made little more noise than Perrin, the faint crunch of boots in snow. It was no shock that Marline moved through the trees as if she had grown up in a forest instead of the Aiel Waste, where anything that could be called a tree was rare and snow unheard of, though it seemed that all of her necklaces and bracelets should have made some clatter as they swung, but Annoura climbed with almost as little effort, floundering a little with her skirts but deftly avoiding the sharp thorns of dead cat'sclaw and wait-a-minute vines. Aes Sedai usually found a way to surprise you. She managed to keep a wary eye on Grady, too, though the Asha'man appeared to be focused on putting one foot in front of the other. Sometimes he sighed heavily and paused for a minute, frowning toward the crest ahead, but somehow he never fell behind. Gallenne and Arganda were not young men, nor accustomed to walking where they could ride, and their breathing began to grow heavier as they ascended, sometimes pulling themselves up from tree to tree, but they watched one another nearly as much as they did the ground, each unwilling to let the other outdo him.

ðə fɔɹ ɡildænɪn lænsɝz, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, slɪpt ən slɪd, tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ ɹuts hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə snoʊ, kɑt ðɛɹ skæbɝdz ɑn vaɪnz, ən ɡɹaʊl kɝsɪz wən ðeɪ fɛl ɑn ɹɑks əɹ wɝ stæbd baɪ θɔɹnz. pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə kənsɪɾɝ sɛndɪŋ əm bæk tə weɪt wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. ðæt, əɹ hɪɾɪŋ əm oʊvɝ ðə hɛɾ ən livɪŋ əm tə bi pɪkt ʌp wən i ɹɪtɝnd.

The four Ghealdanin lancers, on the other hand, slipped and slid, tripped over roots hidden beneath the snow, caught their scabbards on vines, and growled curses when they fell on rocks or were stabbed by thorns. Perrin began to consider sending them back to wait with the horses. That, or hitting them over the head and leaving them to be picked up when he returned.

əbɹʌpli, tu il stɛpt aʊɾ ə ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛlaɪəs, dɑɹk veɪlz haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ði aɪz, waɪt kloʊks hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ bæks ən spɪɹz ən bʌklɝz ɪn hænd. ðeɪ wɝ meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ baɪ ðɛɹ haɪt, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əm noʊ lɛs deɪnʒɝəs ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ælɡeɪdnswaɪ, ən ɪn ən ɪnstənt, naɪn lɔŋboʊz wɝ dʒɹɔn, bɹɔdhɛd pɔɪns eɪmd ət ðɛɹ hɑɹts. "ju kəd ɡɛt hɝt ðət weɪ, tuænhə," ɛlaɪəs mʌɾɝd. "ju ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ, səlɪn." pɛɹɪn moʊʃən fəɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn tə loʊɝ ðɛɹ baʊz, ən fəɹ ɛɹæm tə loʊɝ ɪz sɔɹd. hi hæd kɑt ðɛɹ sɛns əz sun əz ɛlaɪəs hæd, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ stɛpt ɪndə ði oʊpən.

Abruptly, two Aiel stepped out of the undergrowth in front of Elyas, dark veils hiding their faces to the eyes, white cloaks hanging down their backs and spears and bucklers in hand. They were Maidens of the Spear by their height, which made them no less dangerous than any other algai'd'nswai, and in an instant, nine longbows were drawn, broadhead points aimed at their hearts. "You could get hurt that way, Tuandha," Elyas muttered. "You should know better, Sulin." Perrin motioned for the Two Rivers men to lower their bows, and for Aram to lower his sword. He had caught their scents as soon as Elyas had, before they stepped into the open.

ðə meɪɾənz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd stɑɹɾəld lʊks, bʌt ðeɪ ənveɪld, lɛɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk veɪlz hæŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts. "ju si kloʊsli, ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə," səlɪn sɛd. wɪɹi ən lɛðɝ-feɪst, wɪð ə skɑɹ əkɹɔs wʌn tʃik, ʃi hæd ʃɑɹp blu aɪz ðət kəd pɪɹs laɪk ɔlz, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, naʊ. tuænhə wɑz tɔlɝ ən jʌŋɡɝ, ən ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi bɪfɔɹ luzɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪɾ aɪ ən ɡeɪnɪŋ ə θɪk skɑɹ ðən ɹæn fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn ʌp ʌndɝ əɹ sboʊufə. ɪt pʊld ʌp wʌn kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maʊθ ɪn ə hæf-smaɪl, bʌt ðət wɑz ði oʊnli smaɪl ʃi ɛvɝ ɡeɪv.

The Maidens exchanged startled looks, but they unveiled, letting the dark veils hang down their chests. "You see closely, Elyas Machera," Sulin said. Wiry and leather-faced, with a scar across one cheek, she had sharp blue eyes that could pierce like awls, but they still looked surprised, now. Tuandha was taller and younger, and she might have been pretty before losing her right eye and gaining a thick scar than ran from her chin up under her sboufa. It pulled up one corner of her mouth in a half-smile, but that was the only smile she ever gave.

"jɔɹ koʊts ɑɹ dɪfɹənt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. tuænhə fɹaʊn daʊn əɾ əɹ koʊt, ɔl ɡɹeɪ ən ɡɹin ən bɹaʊn, ðən ət səlɪnz aɪdɛntɪkəl ɡɑɹmənt. "jɔɹ kloʊks, tu." ɛlaɪəs wɑz taɪɝd, tə meɪk ðət slɪp.

"Your coats are different," Perrin said. Tuandha frowned down at her coat, all gray and green and brown, then at Sulin's identical garment. "Your cloaks, too." Elyas was tired, to make that slip.

"ðeɪ hævən stɑɹɾəd muvɪŋ, hæv ðeɪ?"

"They haven't started moving, have they?"

"noʊ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," səlɪn sɛd. "ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sim pɹipɛɹd tə steɪ ɪn wʌn pleɪs fəɹ ə taɪm. ðeɪ meɪd ðə pipəl fɹəm ðə sɪɾi liv ən ɡoʊ nɔɹθ læs naɪt, ðoʊz ðeɪ wəd lɛt liv." ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, stɪl pɝtɝbd baɪ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ fɔɹsɪŋ pipəl tə bɪkʌm ɡeɪʃeɪn u dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ. "jɔɹ fɹɛnz dʒɑndɪn bæɹən ən ɡɛɾ eɪliə ən hu mɑɹwɪn əv ɡɔn æftɝ əm tə si ɪf ðeɪ kən lɝn ɛniθɪŋ. əɹ spɪɹ-sɪstɝz ən ɡɔl ɑɹ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ ɝaʊn ðə kæmp əɡɛn.

"No, Perrin Aybara," Sulin said. "The Shaido seem prepared to stay in one place for a time. They made the people from the city leave and go north last night, those they would let leave." She gave a small shake of her head, still perturbed by the Shaido forcing people to become gai'shain who did not follow ji'e'toh. "Your friends Jondyn Barran and Get Ayliah and Hu Marwin have gone after them to see if they can learn anything. Our spear-sisters and Gaul are making their way around the camp again.

wi weɪɾəd hɪɹ fəɹ ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə tə ɹɪtɝn wɪð ju." ʃi sɛldəm lɛɾ ɪmoʊʃən ɪndə hɝ vɔɪs, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌn ðəɹ naʊ, bʌt ʃi smɛld ə sædnəs. "kʌm, əl ʃoʊ ju." ðə tu meɪɾənz tɝn ʌp ðə sloʊp, ən i hɝiɾ æftɝ ðɛm, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛls. ə lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə kɹɛst, ðeɪ kɹaʊtʃt, ðən wɛn tə hænz ən niz, ən i kɑpid ðɛm, kɹɔlɪŋ ðə læst spænz θɹu ðə snoʊ tə pɪɹ pæst ə tʃɹi oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə ðə ɹɪdʒəlaɪn. ðə fɔɹəst ɛndəd ðɛɹ, feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə skæɾɝd bɹʌʃ ən aɪsəleɪɾəd sæplɪŋz ɑn ðə daʊnsloʊp. hi wɑz haɪ ɪnʌf tə si fəɹ sɛvɹəl liɡz, əkɹɔs ɹoʊlɪŋ ɹɪdʒəz laɪk lɔŋ tʃɹiləs hɪlz tə wɛɹ ə dɑɹk bæn ə fɔɹəs bɪɡæn əɡɛn. hi kəd si ɛvɹiθɪŋ i wɑntəd tə si, ən soʊ mʌtʃ lɛs ðən i niɾəd. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmædʒən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp fɹəm ɛlaɪəs' dɪskɹɪpʃən, bʌt ðə ɹiæləɾi dwɔɹft ɪz ɪmædʒɪnɪŋz. ə θaʊzən peɪsɪz bɪloʊ leɪ ə mæs ə loʊ il tɛns ən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ sɔɹɾ ə tɛnt, ə mæs ʌv wæɡənz ən kɑɹts ən pipəl ən hɔɹsəz. ɪt spɹɛd fəɹ wɛl oʊvɝ ə maɪl ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɔlz ʌv ə sɪɾi hæfweɪ tə ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz. hi nu ðə spɹɔl mʌs bi ðə seɪm ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz, nɑt laɪk keɪɛmlɪn əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, lɛs ðən fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz waɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə saɪɾ i kəd si ən nɛɹoʊɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝz, ɪt simd, bʌt stɪl ə sɪɾi wɪð haɪ wɔlz ən taʊɝz ən wʌt lʊk laɪk ə fɔɹtʃɹəs ət ðə nɔɹðmoʊst ɛnd. jɛt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɛnkæmpmən swɑloʊɾ ɪt hoʊl. feɪl wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðət ɡɹeɪt leɪk ə pipəl. fʌmbəlɪŋ ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, hi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ət ðə læst ɪnstən tə kʌp wʌn hæn fəɹ ʃeɪɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə tub. ðə sʌn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən bɔl ɔlmoʊst əhɛɾ ə hɪm, dʒʌst ʃaɪ ʌv hæfweɪ tə ɪts nundeɪ haɪt. ə stʃɹeɪ ɹəflɛkʃən fɹəm ðə lɛnz kəd ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɡɹups ə pipəl lɛpt ʌp ɪn ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs, ðɛɹ feɪsəz klɪɹ, ət lis tə hɪz aɪ. lɔŋ-hɛɹd wɪmən wɪð dɑɹk ʃɔlz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, dʒɹeɪpt ɪn dʌzənz ə lɔŋ nɛkləsɪz, wɪmən wɪð fjuɝ nɛkləsɪz mɪlkɪŋ ɡoʊts, wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ ən səmtaɪmz kæɹiɪŋ spɪɹz ən bʌklɝz, wɪmən pikɪŋ fɹəm ðə dip kaʊlz ə hɛvi waɪt ɹoʊbz əz ðeɪ skɝiɾ əkɹɔs snoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɹæmpəl hæfweɪ tə mʌd. ðəɹ wɝ mɛn ən tʃɪlʒɹən, tu, bʌɾ ɪz aɪ skɪpt pæst əm hʌŋɡɹəli, ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. θaʊzənz əpɑn θaʊzənz ʌv wɪmən, dʒʌs kaʊntɪŋ ðoʊz ɪn waɪt. "tu mɛni," mɑɹlaɪn wɪspɝd, ən i loʊɝd ðə ɡlæs tə ɡlɛɹ ət hɝ. ði ʌðɝz hæd dʒɔɪn ðə meɪɾənz ən hɪm, ɔl laɪɪŋ ɪn ə ɹoʊ ɪn ðə snoʊ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪdʒəlaɪn.

We waited here for Elyas Machera to return with you." She seldom let emotion into her voice, and there was none there now, but she smelled of sadness. "Come, I will show you." The two Maidens turned up the slope, and he hurried after them, forgetting anyone else. A little short of the crest, they crouched, then went to hands and knees, and he copied them, crawling the last spans through the snow to peer past a tree over the top of the ridgeline. The forest ended there, fading into scattered brush and isolated saplings on the downslope. He was high enough to see for several leagues, across rolling ridges like long treeless hills to where a dark band of forest began again. He could see everything he wanted to see, and so much less than he needed. He had tried to imagine the Shaido camp from Elyas' description, but the reality dwarfed his imaginings. A thousand paces below lay a mass of low Aiel tents and every other sort of tent, a mass of wagons and carts and people and horses. It spread for well over a mile in every direction from the gray stone walls of a city halfway to the next rise. He knew the sprawl must be the same on the other side. It was not one of the great cities, not like Caemlyn or Tar Valon, less than four hundred paces wide along the side he could see and narrower on the others, it seemed, but still a city with high walls and towers and what looked like a fortress at the northmost end. Yet the Shaido encampment swallowed it whole. Faile was somewhere in that great lake of people. Fumbling his looking glass from his pocket, he remembered at the last instant to cup one hand for shade on the far end of the tube. The sun was a golden ball almost ahead of him, just shy of halfway to its noonday height. A stray reflection from the lens could ruin everything. Groups of people leapt up in the looking glass, their faces clear, at least to his eye. Long-haired women with dark shawls over their shoulders, draped in dozens of long necklaces, women with fewer necklaces milking goats, women wearing the cadin'sor and sometimes carrying spears and bucklers, women peeking from the deep cowls of heavy white robes as they scurried across snow already trampled halfway to mud. There were men and children, too, but his eye skipped past them hungrily, ignored them. Thousands upon thousands of women, just counting those in white. "Too many," Marline whispered, and he lowered the glass to glare at her. The others had joined the Maidens and him, all lying in a row in the snow along the ridgeline.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ teɪkɪŋ peɪnz tə kip ðɛɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋz ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ðɛɹ baʊz əbʌv ðə ɹɪdʒəlaɪn. ɑɹɡændə ən ɡælɛn wɝ juzɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz tə stʌɾi ðə kæmp bɪloʊ, ən ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp wɪð ɪz tʃɪn pɹɑpt ɑn ɪz hænz, ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz ɪntɛn əz ðə tu soʊlʒɝz. meɪbi hi wɑz juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ɪn səm weɪ. mɑɹlaɪn ən ənʊɹə wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kæmp, tu, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps ən ðə waɪz wʌn fɹaʊnɪŋ. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk mɑɹlaɪn hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə spik əlaʊd.

The Two Rivers men were taking pains to keep their bowstrings up out of the snow without raising their bows above the ridgeline. Arganda and Gallenne were using their own looking glasses to study the camp below, and Grady was staring down the slope with his chin propped on his hands, every bit as intent as the two soldiers. Maybe he was using the Power in some way. Marline and Annoura were staring at the camp, too, the Aes Sedai licking her lips and the Wise One frowning. Perrin did not think Marline had intended to speak aloud.

"ɪf jə θɪŋk əl wɔk əweɪ dʒʌs kəz ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ʃeɪɾoʊ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd," hi bɪɡæn hiɾɪdli, bʌt ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn, miɾɪŋ ɪz skaʊl wɪð ə lɛvəl lʊk.

"If you think I'll walk away just because there are more Shaido than I expected," he began heatedly, but she broke in, meeting his scowl with a level look.

"tu mɛni waɪz wʌnz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. wɛɹɛvɝ aɪ lʊk, aɪ kən si ə wʊmən tʃænəlɪŋ. dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmən hɪɹ, ə moʊmən ðəɹ - waɪz wʌnz də nɑt tʃænəl ɔl ðə taɪm - bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ aɪ lʊk. tu mɛni tə bi ðə waɪz wʌnz ɔfən sɛps." hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "haʊ mɛni dʒju θɪŋk ðəɹ ɑɹ?" "aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi ɔl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ daʊn ðɛɹ," mɑɹlaɪn ɹɪplaɪd, əz kɑm əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pɹaɪs ə bɑɹli. "ɔl u kən tʃænəl." ɔl ə ðɛm? ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns! haʊ kəd ðeɪ ɔl bi təɡɛðɝ hɪɹ, wən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sim tə bi skæɾɝd ɛvɹiwɛɹ? ət list, hi hæd hɝd teɪlz ʌv wʌt hæd tə bi ʃeɪɾoʊ ɹeɪdz ɔl əkɹɔs ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, teɪlz ə ɹeɪdz hɪɹ ɪn ɔltɑɹə lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ feɪl wɑz teɪkən ən ɹumɝz fɹəm ivən fɑɹðɝ. waɪ wəd ðeɪ ɔl bi təɡɛðɝ? ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪntɛndəd tə ɡæðɝ hɪɹ, ðə hoʊl klæn. . . . noʊ, hi hæd tə dil wɪð wʌɾ i nu fəɹ fækt. ðət wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf. "haʊ mɛni?" hi æskt əɡɛn, ɪn ə ɹizənəbəl toʊn. "du nɑt ɡɹaʊl ət mi, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. aɪ kænɑt seɪ ɪɡzækli haʊ mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv. ivən waɪz wʌnz daɪ fɹəm sɪknəs, sneɪkɛbaɪt, æksəɾənt. səm daɪɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz. wi faʊn bɑɾiz lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ən ðeɪ mʌst əv kæɹiɾ əweɪ ðoʊz ðeɪ kəd fəɹ pɹɑpɝ bɛɹiəl. ivən ʃeɪɾoʊ kænɑɾ əv əbændən ɔl kʌstəm. ɪf ɔl u ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv ɑɹ bɪloʊ, ən ði əpɹɛntəsɪz u kən tʃænəl, aɪ wəd seɪ pɝhæps fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd. pɝhæps mɔɹ, bʌt fjuɝ ðən faɪv hʌnʒɹəd. ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ ðən faɪv hʌnʒɹəd ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ən pɝhæps fɪfti əpɹɛntəsɪz." moʊs fɑɹmɝz wʊɾə ʃoʊn mɔɹ ɪmoʊʃən oʊvɝ ðə bɑɹli.

"Too many Wise Ones, Perrin Aybara. Wherever I look, I can see a woman channeling. Just for a moment here, a moment there - Wise Ones do not channel all the time - but they are everywhere I look. Too many to be the Wise Ones often septs." He drew a deep breath. "How many do you think there are?" "I think maybe all the Shaido Wise Ones are down there," Marline replied, as calm as if she were talking about the price of barley. "All who can channel." All of them? That made no sense! How could they all be together here, when the Shaido seemed to be scattered everywhere? At least, he had heard tales of what had to be Shaido raids all across Ghealdan and Amadicia, tales of raids here in Altara long before Faile was taken and rumors from even farther. Why would they all be together? If the Shaido intended to gather here, the whole clan. . . . No, he had to deal with what he knew for fact. That was bad enough. "How many?" he asked again, in a reasonable tone. "Do not growl at me, Perrin Aybara. I cannot say exactly how many Shaido Wise Ones remain alive. Even Wise Ones die from sickness, snakebite, accident. Some died at Dumai's Wells. We found bodies left behind, and they must have carried away those they could for proper burial. Even Shaido cannot have abandoned all custom. If all who remain alive are below, and the apprentices who can channel, I would say perhaps four hundred. Perhaps more, but fewer than five hundred. There were fewer than five hundred Shaido Wise Ones who could channel before they crossed the Dragonwall, and perhaps fifty apprentices." Most farmers would have shown more emotion over the barley.

stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp, ənʊɹə meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊnd, hæf ə sɑb. "faɪv hʌnʒɹəd?

Still staring at the Shaido camp, Annoura made a strangled sound, half a sob. "Five hundred?

laɪt! hæf ðə taʊɝ fɹəm wʌn klæn? oʊ, laɪt!"

Light! Half the Tower from one clan? Oh, Light!"

"wi kəd snik ɪn, ɪn ðə naɪt," dænɪl mɝmɝd fɹəm daʊn ðə ɹoʊ, "ðə weɪ jə snikt ɪndə ðət waɪtkloʊk kæmp bæk hoʊm." ɛlaɪəs ɡeɪv ə ɡɹʌn ðət maɪɾ əv mɛn ɛniθɪŋ bʌt dɪd nɑt saʊn hoʊpfəl.

"We could sneak in, in the night," Dannil murmured from down the row, "the way you sneaked into that Whitecloak camp back home." Elyas gave a grunt that might have meant anything but did not sound hopeful.

səlɪn snɔɹɾɪd dɝɪsɪvli. "wi kəd nɑt snik ɪndə ðət kæmp, nɑt wɪð ɛni ɹil hoʊp ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt. jə wəd bi tʃɹʌs laɪk ə ɡoʊt fəɹ ðə spɪt bɪfɔɹ jə pæs ðə fɝs tɛns." pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli. hi hæd θɔɾ ə slɪpɪŋ ɪn ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ə dɑɹknəs ən sʌmhaʊ spɪɹəɾɪŋ feɪl əweɪ. ən ði ʌðɝz, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wəd nɑt ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝz. hi hæd nɛvɝ hæɾ ɛni ɹil bɪlif ðət kəd wɝk, ðoʊ, nɑɾ əɡɛnst il, ən ðə saɪz ə ðə kæmp hæd kwɛntʃt ðə læst ɡlɪmɝz. hi kəd wɑndɝ fəɹ deɪz əmʌŋ ðət mɛni pipəl wɪθaʊt faɪndɪŋ hɝ. əbɹʌpli, hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt hævɪŋ tə faɪt daʊn dɪspɛɹ. ði æŋɡɝ ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz koʊld əz stil ɪn wɪntɝ, naʊ, ən i kəd nɑt dɪtɛkt ə sɪŋɡəl dʒɹɑp ə ðə hoʊpləsnəs ðət hæd θɹɛɾənd tə dʒɹaʊn ɪm bɪfɔɹ. ðəɹ wɝ tɛn θaʊzən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ ɪn ðət kæmp, ən faɪv hʌnʒɹəd wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl - ɡælɛn hæd ðə ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɪt; pɹipɛɹ fəɹ ðə wɝst, ən ɔl jəɹ sɝpɹaɪzəz wɝ plɛzənt wʌnz - faɪv hʌnʒɹəd wɪmən u wəd nɑt hɛzəteɪt tə juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən; feɪl wɑz hɪɾən laɪk wʌn snoʊfleɪk ɪn ə mɛdoʊ kʌvɝd wɪð snoʊ, bʌt wən jə paɪld ʌp soʊ mʌtʃ, ðəɹ dʒʌst wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn dɪspɛɹ. jə hæd tə bʌkəl daʊn əɹ bi plaʊɾ ʌndɝ. bɪsaɪdz, hi kəd si ðə pʌzəl, naʊ. næt tɔɹfɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɛni pʌzəl kəd bi sɑlvd, wʌns jə faʊn aʊt wɛɹ tə pʊʃ ən wɛɹ tə pʊl.

Sulin snorted derisively. "We could not sneak into that camp, not with any real hope of getting out. You would be trussed like a goat for the spit before you passed the first tents." Perrin nodded slowly. He had thought of slipping in under cover of darkness and somehow spiriting Faile away. And the others, of course. She would not go without the others. He had never had any real belief that could work, though, not against Aiel, and the size of the camp had quenched the last glimmers. He could wander for days among that many people without finding her. Abruptly, he realized that he was not having to fight down despair. The anger remained, but it was cold as steel in winter, now, and he could not detect a single drop of the hopelessness that had threatened to drown him before. There were ten thousand algai'd'siswai in that camp, and five hundred women who could channel - Gallenne had the right of it; prepare for the worst, and all your surprises were pleasant ones - five hundred women who would not hesitate to use the Power as a weapon; Faile was hidden like one snowflake in a meadow covered with snow, but when you piled up so much, there just was no point in despair. You had to buckle down or be plowed under. Besides, he could see the puzzle, now. Nat Torfinn had always said any puzzle could be solved, once you found out where to push and where to pull.

tə ðə nɔɹθ ən saʊθ, ðə læn hæd bɪn klɪɹd fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ðən ðə ɹaɪz wɛɹ i leɪ.

To the north and south, the land had been cleared farther from the city than the rise where he lay.

skæɾɝd fɑɹmhaʊsəz, nʌn wɪð smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪts tʃɪmni, dɑɾəd ðə lændskeɪp, ən ɹeɪl fɛnsəz mɑɹkt aʊt filz bɪniθ ðə snoʊ, bʌt mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ə mɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əpɹoʊtʃ fɹəm iðɝ dɝɛkʃən maɪɾ əz wɛl kæɹi tɔɹtʃɪz ən bænɝz ən bloʊ tʃɹʌmpəts. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə ɹoʊd liɾɪŋ ɹʌfli saʊθ θɹu ðə fɑɹmz ən ənʌðɝ ɹʌfli nɔɹθ. jusləs tə hɪm, pɹɑbli, bʌt jə nɛvɝ kəd tɛl. dʒɑndɪn maɪt bɹɪŋ bæk səm ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əbaʊt ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ wʌt ɡʊd ðət wəd də wən ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, hi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɡɛs. ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz u wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ ɝaʊn ðə kæmp wəd bi eɪbəl tə tɛl ɪm wʌt leɪ bɪɑn ðə nɛkst ɹɪdʒ. ə sæɾəl ɪn ðət ɹɪdʒ hæd ðə lʊk ʌv ə ɹoʊd hɛɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ist. ɑdli, ə klʌstɝ ʌv wɪndmɪlz stʊd meɪbi ə maɪl nɔɹθ ə ðə sæɾəl, lɔŋ waɪɾ ɑɹmz tɝnɪŋ sloʊli, ən ðəɹ əpɪɹd tə ənʌðɝ ɡɹup ʌv wɪndmɪlz ətɑp ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz bɪɑnd. ə ɹoʊ ʌv ɑɹtʃəz, laɪk ə lɔŋ nɛɹoʊ bɹɪdʒ, stʃɹɛtʃt daʊn ðə sloʊp fɹəm ðə nɪɹəst wɪndmɪlz ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɪɾi wɔlz.

Scattered farmhouses, none with smoke rising from its chimney, dotted the landscape, and rail fences marked out fields beneath the snow, but more than a handful of men trying to approach from either direction might as well carry torches and banners and blow trumpets. There seemed to be a road leading roughly south through the farms and another roughly north. Useless to him, probably, but you never could tell. Jondyn might bring back some information about the city, though what good that would do when the city was in the middle of the Shaido, he could not begin to guess. Gaul and the Maidens who were making their way around the camp would be able to tell him what lay beyond the next ridge. A saddle in that ridge had the look of a road heading somewhere east. Oddly, a cluster of windmills stood maybe a mile north of the saddle, long white arms turning slowly, and there appeared to another group of windmills atop the next rise beyond. A row of arches, like a long narrow bridge, stretched down the slope from the nearest windmills all the way to the city walls.

"dʌz ɛnibəɾi noʊ wʌt ðəɾ ɪz?" hi æskt, pɔɪntɪŋ. stʌɾiɪŋ ɪt θɹu ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs toʊld ɪm nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt simd meɪɾ ə ðə seɪm ɡɹeɪ stoʊn əz ðə wɔl. ðə θɪŋ wɑz mʌtʃ tu nɛɹoʊ fəɹ ə bɹɪdʒ. ɪt læk saɪd wɔlz, ən ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ ə bɹɪdʒ tə kɹɔs. "ɪɾ ɪz fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ wɔɾɝ," səlɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt ɹʌnz fəɹ faɪv maɪlz, tə ə leɪk. aɪ də nɑt noʊ waɪ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɪl ðɛɹ sɪɾi kloʊsɝ, bʌt moʊst ə ðə læn ɝaʊn ðə leɪk lʊks əz ɪf ɪɾəl bi mʌd wən ðə koʊld ɡoʊz əweɪ." ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ stʌmbəld oʊvɝ ʌnfəmɪljɝ wɝdz laɪk mʌd, jɛɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɑ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn "leɪk," ɪn ði aɪdiə ʌv soʊ mʌtʃ wɔɾɝ ɪn wʌn pleɪs. "ju θɪŋk tə stɑp ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ səplaɪ? ðət wɪl ʃʊɹli meɪk əm kʌm aʊt." ʃi ʌndɝstʊd faɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ wɔɾɝ. moʊs faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪst stɑɹɾəd wɪð wɔɾɝ.

"Does anybody know what that is?" he asked, pointing. Studying it through the looking glass told him nothing except that it seemed made of the same gray stone as the wall. The thing was much too narrow for a bridge. It lacked side walls, and there did not seem to be anything for a bridge to cross. "It is for bringing water," Sulin replied. "It runs for five miles, to a lake. I do not know why they did not build their city closer, but most of the land around the lake looks as if it will be mud when the cold goes away." She no longer stumbled over unfamiliar words like mud, yet a touch of awe remained in "lake," in the idea of so much water in one place. "You think to stop their water supply? That will surely make them come out." She understood fighting over water. Most fighting in the Waste started with water.

"bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk -"

"But I do not think -"

ðə kʌlɝz ɪɹʌptəɾ ɪnsaɪd pɛɹɪnz hɛd, ən ɪksploʊʒən ə hjuz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət saɪɾ ən hɪɹɪŋ vænɪʃt. ɔl saɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə kʌlɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, ət list. ðeɪ wɝ ə væs taɪd, əz ɪf ɔl ðə taɪmz i hæd pʊʃt əm aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd hæd bɪlt ə dæm ðət ðeɪ naʊ smæʃt əsaɪɾ ɪn ə saɪlən flʌd, swɝlɪŋ ɪn saʊnləs wɝlpulz ðət tʃɹaɪd tə sʌk ɪm ʌndɝ. ən ɪmədʒ koʊəlɛst ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt, ɹænd ən nɪneɪiv sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn feɪsɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, əz klɪɹ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. hi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɹænd, nɑt naʊ. nɑt naʊ! klɔɪŋ ət ðə kʌlɝz laɪk ə dʒɹaʊnɪŋ mæn klɔɪŋ fəɹ ðə sɝfəs, hi  -  fɔɹst  -  ðɛm  -  aʊt! saɪɾ ən hɪɹɪŋ, ðə wɝld ɝaʊnd, kɹæʃt ɪn ɑn hɪm.

The colors erupted inside Perrin's head, an explosion of hues so strong that sight and hearing vanished. All sight except for the colors themselves, at least. They were a vast tide, as if all the times he had pushed them out of his head had built a dam that they now smashed aside in a silent flood, swirling in soundless whirlpools that tried to suck him under. An image coalesced in the middle of it, Rand and Nynaeve sitting on the ground facing one another, as clear as if they were right in front of him. He had no time for Rand, not now. Not now! Clawing at the colors like a drowning man clawing for the surface, he  -  forced  -  them  -  out! Sight and hearing, the world around, crashed in on him.

". . . ɪts mædnəs," ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪn wɝid toʊnz. "noʊbɑdi kən hændəl ɪnʌf ə seɪɾɪn fəɹ mi tə fil ðət fɑɹ ɔf! noʊbɑdi!"

". . . it's madness," Grady was saying in worried tones. "Nobody can handle enough of saidin for me to feel that far off! Nobody!"

"noʊ wʌn kən hændəl ðət mʌtʃ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, iðɝ," mɑɹlaɪn mɝmɝd.

"No one can handle that much of saidar, either," Marline murmured.

"bʌt sʌmwʌn ɪz."

"But someone is."

"ðə fɔɹseɪkən?" ənʊɹəz vɔɪs ʃʊk. "ðə fɔɹseɪkən, juzɪŋ səm sɑŋɡɹil wi nɛvɝ səspɛktəd. əɹ . . . əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf."

"The Forsaken?" Annoura's voice shook. "The Forsaken, using some sa'angreal we never suspected. Or . . . or the Dark One himself."

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl θɹi piɹɪŋ bæk tə ðə nɔɹθ ən wɛst, ən ɪf mɑɹlaɪn lʊkt kɑmɝ ðən ənʊɹə əɹ ɡɹeɪɾi, ʃi smɛld əz fɹaɪɾənd ən wɝid. ɪksɛp fəɹ ɛlaɪəs, ði ʌðɝz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðoʊz θɹi wɪð ðə lʊk ə mɛn əweɪɾɪŋ ən ənaʊnsmən ðəɾ ə nu bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝl hæd bɪɡʌn. ɛlaɪəsəz feɪs wɑz æksɛptɪŋ. ə wʊlf wəd snæp əɾ ə lændslaɪd kæɹiɪŋ ɪm tə hɪz dɛθ, bʌɾ ə wʊlf nu ðət dɛθ keɪm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən jə kəd nɑt faɪt dɛθ.

They were all three peering back to the north and west, and if Marline looked calmer than Annoura or Grady, she smelled as frightened and worried. Except for Elyas, the others were watching those three with the look of men awaiting an announcement that a new Breaking of the World had begun. Elyas's face was accepting. A wolf would snap at a landslide carrying him to his death, but a wolf knew that death came sooner or later, and you could not fight death.

"ɪts ɹænd," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd θɪkli. hi ʃʌɾɝəd əz ðə kʌlɝz tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪtɝn, bʌɾ i hæmɝɾ əm daʊn. "hɪz bɪznəs. hɪl teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɪt, wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz." ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ivən ɛlaɪəs. "aɪ nid pɹɪznɝz, səlɪn. ðeɪ mʌst sɛn aʊt hʌntɪŋ pɑɹɾiz. ɛlaɪəs sɛz ðeɪv sɛntʃɹiz aʊɾ ə fju maɪlz, smɔl ɡɹups. kən jə ɡɛt mi pɹɪznɝz?"

"It's Rand," Perrin muttered thickly. He shuddered as the colors tried to return, but he hammered them down. "His business. He'll take care of it, whatever it is." Everyone was staring at him, even Elyas. "I need prisoners, Sulin. They must send out hunting parties. Elyas says they have sentries out a few miles, small groups. Can you get me prisoners?"

"lɪsən tə mi kɛɹfəli," ənʊɹə sɛd, ðə wɝdz ɹʌʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ. ʃi ɹoʊz ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ oʊvɝ mɑɹlaɪn ən siz ə fɪsfəl ə pɛɹɪnz kloʊk. "sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ, pɝhæps wʌndɝfəl, pɝhæps tɛɹəbəl, bʌɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs moʊmɛntəs, mɔɹ soʊ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ɹəkɔɹɾəd hɪstɝi! wi mʌs noʊ wʌt! ɡɹeɪɾi kən teɪk əs ðɛɹ, kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si. aɪ kəd teɪk əs ɪf aɪ nu ðə wivz. wi mʌs noʊ!"

"Listen to me carefully," Annoura said, the words rushing out of her. She rose up out of the snow enough to reach over Marline and seize a fistful of Perrin's cloak. "Something is happening, perhaps wonderful, perhaps terrible, but in any case momentous, more so than anything in recorded history! We must know what! Grady can take us there, close enough to see. I could take us if I knew the weaves. We must know!"

miɾɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪz, pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd, ən ʃi stɑpt wɪð əɹ maʊθ oʊpən. ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ ʃʌɾ ʌp ðəɾ izəli, jɛt ʃi dɪd. "aɪ toʊl jə wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. əɹ wɝk ɪz ɹaɪt daʊn ðəɹ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌs. səlɪn?" səlɪnz hɛd swʌŋ fɹəm ɪm tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə mɑɹlaɪn. faɪnəli, ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "ju wɪl lɝn lɪɾəl jusfəl ivən ɪf jə pʊɾ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən. ðəl ɛmbɹeɪs ðə peɪn ən læf ət ju. ən ʃeɪm wɪl bi sloʊ  -  ɪf ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ kən stɪl bi ʃeɪmd." "wʌtɛvɝ aɪ lɝn wɪl bi mɔɹ ðən aɪ noʊ naʊ," hi ɹɪplaɪd. hɪz wɝk leɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ə pʌzəl tə sɑlv, feɪl tə fɹi, ən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ. ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd ɪn ðə wɝld.

Meeting her gaze, Perrin raised his hand, and she stopped with her mouth open. Aes Sedai never shut up that easily, yet she did. "I told you what it is. Our work is right down there in front of us. Sulin?" Sulin's head swung from him to the Aes Sedai to Marline. Finally, she shrugged. "You will learn little useful even if you put them to the question. They will embrace the pain and laugh at you. And shame will be slow  -  if these Shaido can still be shamed." "Whatever I learn will be more than I know now," he replied. His work lay in front of him. A puzzle to solve, Faile to free, and the Shaido to destroy. That was all that mattered in the world.

tʃæptɝ naɪn

CHAPTER 9

tʃɹæps "ænd ʃi kəmpleɪn əɡɛn ðət ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ tɪmɪd," feɪl fɪnɪʃt ɪn əɹ bɛs mik vɔɪs, ʃɪftɪŋ ðə tɔl bæskət ʃi hɛl bælənst ɑn wʌn ʃoʊldɝ, ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm fʊt tə fʊɾ ɪn ðə mʌɾi snoʊ. ðə bæskət wɑz nɑt hɛvi, ðoʊ fɪld wɪð dɝɾi lɔnʒɹi, ən ðə wʊl ə hɝ waɪt ɹoʊb wɑz θɪk ən wɔɹm, wɪð tu ʌndɝ-ɹoʊbz bɪniθ, bʌɾ əɹ sɑf lɛðɝ buts, ðɛmsɛlvz blitʃt waɪt, ɡeɪv lɪɾəl pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm ðə koʊl slʌʃ. "aɪ wɑz toʊl tə ɹipɔɹt wʌt ðə waɪz wʌn sɪvænə sɛɾ ɪɡzækli," ʃi æɾəd kwɪkli. sʌmɛɝɪn wɑz wʌn ə ði "ʌðɝ" waɪz wʌnz, ən əɹ maʊθ hæd tɝn daʊn ət ðə wɝd tɪmɪd. wɪð əɹ aɪz loʊɝd, ðət wɑz ɔl feɪl kəd si ʌv sʌmɛɝɪnz feɪs. ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd tə meɪnteɪn ə hʌmbəl mænɝ, ɪspɛʃli ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn u wɝ nɑɾ il, ən ðoʊ ʃi lʊkt ʌp θɹu hɝ aɪlæʃɪz tə ɹid sʌmɛɝɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən, ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, ivən il mɛn, ə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd dʒaɪən u taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ hɝ. moʊst ʌv wʌt ʃi kəd si wɑz sʌmɛɝɪnz oʊvɝ-lɑɹdʒ bʊzəm, plʌmp sʌn-dɑɹk klivədʒ ɪkspoʊz baɪ ə blaʊs ənleɪs hæfweɪ daʊn əɹ tʃɛst ən kʌvɝd meɪnli baɪ ə mæsɪv kəlɛkʃən ə lɔŋ nɛkləsɪz, faɪɝdʒɹɑps ən ɛmɹəlz, ɹubiz ən oʊpəlz, θɹi-tiɹd stʃɹænz ə fæt pɝlz ən ɪntʃɹəkətli pæɾɝnd tʃeɪnz ʌv ɡoʊld. moʊst ə ðə waɪz wʌnz sim tə dɪslaɪk sɪvænə, hu "spoʊk fəɹ ðə tʃif əntɪl ə nu ʃeɪɾoʊ klæn tʃif kəd bi tʃoʊzən, ən ɪvɛn ənlaɪkli tə əkɝ ɛni taɪm sun, ən ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ʌndɝkʌɾ əɹ əθɔɹəɾi wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt skwɑbəlɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əɹ fɔɹmɪŋ klɪks, bʌt mɛni ʃɛɹd sɪvænəz lʌv ʌv wɛtləndɝ dʒuəlɹi, ən səm hæɾ ivən bɪɡʌn wɛɹɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz, laɪk sɪvænə. ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn sʌmɛɝɪn wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ waɪɾ oʊpəl ðət flæʃt kævɝnz ə ɹɛd wɛnɛvɝ ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl, ən ə lɔŋ blu sæfaɪɝ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɹubiz ɑn ðə lɛft. ʃi hæd nɑɾ ədɑptəd sɪlk kloʊðɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. hɝ blaʊs wɑz pleɪn waɪɾ ælɡoʊd, fɹəm ðə weɪst, ən əɹ skɝɾ ən ʃɔl θɪk wʊl əz dɑɹk əz ðə foʊldəd skɑɹf ðət hɛld əɹ weɪst-lɔŋ jɛloʊ hɛɹ bæk fɹəm əɹ feɪs. ðə koʊl dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə dɪskʌmfɝɾ əɹ ɪn ðə list. ðə tu ʌv əm stʊd dʒʌs bɪɑnd wʌt feɪl θɔɾ ʌv əz ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kæmp ən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn kæmp - ðə pɹɪznɝz' kæmp - nɑt ðət ðəɹ ɹɪli wɝ tu kæmps. ə fju ɡeɪʃeɪn slɛpt əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌt ðə ɹɛst wɝ kɛp tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kæmp ənlɛs duɪŋ ðɛɹ əsaɪnd wɝk, kæɾəl fɛnst ɔf fɹəm ðə lʊɹ ə fɹiɾəm baɪ ə wɔl ə ʃeɪɾoʊ. moʊst ə ðə mɛn ən wɪmən u pæst əm wɔɹ waɪt ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz, ðoʊ fju əz faɪnli woʊvən əz wʌt ʃi wɔɹ. wɪð soʊ mɛni tə kloʊð, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ skupt ʌp ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv waɪt klɔθ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd. səm wɝ ɡɑɹbd ɪn leɪɝz ə kɔɹs lɪnən əɹ taʊəlɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊbz ə ɹʌf tɛn klɔθ, ən mɛni ʌv ðə ɹoʊbz wɝ steɪnd wɪð mʌɾ əɹ sʊt.

Traps "And she complained again that the other Wise Ones are timid," Faile finished in her best meek voice, shifting the tall basket she held balanced on one shoulder, shifting from foot to foot in the muddy snow. The basket was not heavy, though filled with dirty laundry, and the wool of her white robe was thick and warm, with two under-robes beneath, but her soft leather boots, themselves bleached white, gave little protection from the cold slush. "I was told to report what the Wise One Sevanna said exactly," she added quickly. Someryn was one of the "other" Wise Ones, and her mouth had turned down at the word timid. With her eyes lowered, that was all Faile could see of Someryn's face. Gai'shain were required to maintain a humble manner, especially the gai'shain who were not Aiel, and though she looked up through her eyelashes to read Someryn's expression, the other woman was taller than most men, even Aiel men, a yellow-haired giant who towered over her. Most of what she could see was Someryn's over-large bosom, plump sun-dark cleavage exposed by a blouse unlaced halfway down her chest and covered mainly by a massive collection of long necklaces, firedrops and emeralds, rubies and opals, three-tiered strands of fat pearls and intricately patterned chains of gold. Most of the Wise Ones seemed to dislike Sevanna, who "spoke for the chief until a new Shaido clan chief could be chosen, an event unlikely to occur any time soon, and they tried to undercut her authority whenever they were not squabbling among themselves or forming cliques, but many shared Sevanna's love of wetlander jewelry, and some had even begun wearing finger rings, like Sevanna. On her right hand Someryn wore a large white opal that flashed caverns of red whenever she adjusted her shawl, and a long blue sapphire surrounded by rubies on the left. She had not adopted silk clothing, however. Her blouse was plain white algode, from the Waste, and her skirt and shawl thick wool as dark as the folded scarf that held her waist-long yellow hair back from her face. The cold did not appear to discomfort her in the least. The two of them stood just beyond what Faile thought of as the border between the Shaido camp and the gai'shain camp - the prisoners' camp - not that there really were two camps. A few gai'shain slept among the Shaido, but the rest were kept to the center of the camp unless doing their assigned work, cattle fenced off from the lure of freedom by a wall of Shaido. Most of the men and women who passed them wore white gai'shain robes, though few as finely woven as what she wore. With so many to clothe, the Shaido scooped up any sort of white cloth they could find. Some were garbed in layers of coarse linen or toweling or robes of rough tent cloth, and many of the robes were stained with mud or soot.

oʊnli naʊ ən ðən dɪd wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ʃoʊ ðə haɪɾ ən peɪl aɪz ʌv ən il. ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi wɝ ɹʌɾi-feɪst ɑmɑdɪʃənz, oʊlɪvɛskɪn ɔltɑɹənz, ən peɪl kɛɹhinɪn, əlɔŋ wɪð əkeɪʒənəl tʃɹævəlɝz əɹ mɝtʃəns fɹəm ɪljən əɹ tæɹɑbən əɹ ɛlswɛɹ u hæd faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðə wɝs pleɪs ət ðə wɝs taɪm. ðə kɛɹhinɪn wɝ ðə lɔŋɡəs hɛld ən moʊst ɹɪzaɪn tə ðɛɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən əsaɪd fɹəm ðə hændfʊl ʌv il ɪn waɪt, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz daʊn ən muvd əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks əz fæst əz ðə tʃɹæmpəl mʌʃ ə snoʊ ən mʌd wəɾ əlaʊ. ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə dɪspleɪ hjumɪlɪɾi, oʊbiɾiəns, ən ən iɡɝnəs tə ɛmbɹeɪs boʊθ. ɛni lɛs ɹɪzʌltɪɾ ɪn peɪnfəl ɹimaɪndɝz.

Only now and then did one of the gai'shain show the height and pale eyes of an Aiel. The vast majority were ruddy-faced Amadicians, oliveskinned Altarans, and pale Cairhienin, along with occasional travelers or merchants from Illian or Tarabon or elsewhere who had found themselves in the worst place at the worst time. The Cairhienin were the longest held and most resigned to their situation aside from the handful of Aiel in white, but they all kept their eyes down and moved about their tasks as fast as the trampled mush of snow and mud would allow. Gai'shain were expected to display humility, obedience, and an eagerness to embrace both. Any less resulted in painful reminders.

feɪl wəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ əv laɪk tə hɝi ɑn hɝsɛlf. koʊl fit wɝ oʊnli ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, ən iɡɝnəs tə də sɪvænəz lɔnʒɹi lɛs. tu mɛni aɪz kəd si hɝ stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ði oʊpən wɪð sʌmɛɝɪn, ən ivən wɪð əɹ dip kaʊl haɪɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs, ðə bɹɔd mɛʃ bɛlt ə ʃaɪni ɡoʊldən lɪŋks ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst ən ə kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ kɑlɝ tə mætʃ mɑɹkt əɹ əz wʌn ə sɪvænəz sɝvəns. noʊ wʌn kɔld əm ðæt  -  ɪn il aɪz, biɪŋ ə sɝvənt wɑz dɪminɪŋ -bʌt ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ, ðə wɛtləndɝz ət list, dʒʌst ənpeɪɾ ən wɪð fjuɝ ɹaɪts ən lɛs fɹiɾəm ðən ɛni sɝvən feɪl hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd tɛl ʌv.

Faile would very much have liked to hurry on herself. Cold feet were only a small part of it, and eagerness to do Sevanna's laundry less. Too many eyes could see her standing there in the open with Someryn, and even with her deep cowl hiding her face, the broad mesh belt of shiny golden links around her waist and a close-fitting collar to match marked her as one of Sevanna's servants. No one called them that  -  in Aiel eyes, being a servant was demeaning -but that was what they were, the wetlanders at least, just unpaid and with fewer rights and less freedom than any servant Faile had ever heard tell of.

sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ sɪvænə hɝsɛlf wɑz gɑnə lɝn ðət waɪz wʌnz wɝ stɑpɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn tə kwɛstʃən ðɛm. sɪvænə hæd wɛl oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd sɝvəns ən kɛpt æɾɪŋ tə ðɛm, ən feɪl wɑz sɝɾən ðəɾ ɛvɹi læst wʌn wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ɛvɹi wɝd ðeɪ hɝd sɪvænə seɪ tə ðə waɪz wʌnz. ɪt wɑz ə bɹuɾəli ɪfɪʃən tʃɹæp. sɪvænə wɑz ə hɑɹʃ mɪstʃɹəs, ɪn ə ɹæðɝ kæʒəwəl weɪ, nɛvɝ snæpɪŋ, sɛldəm oʊpənli æŋɡɹi, bʌt ðə slaɪɾəst ɪnfɹækʃən, ðə smɔləst slɪp ɪn dɪminɝ əɹ bɪheɪvjɝ, wɑz pʌnɪʃt ɪmiɾiətli wɪð ðə swɪtʃ əɹ ðə stʃɹæp, ən ɛvɹi naɪt ðə faɪv ɡeɪʃeɪn u hæd plizd əɹ lis ðət deɪ wɝ tʃoʊzən aʊt fəɹ fɝðɝ pʌnɪʃmənt, səmtaɪmz ə naɪt baʊn ən ɡæɡd ɑn tɑp ʌv ə biɾɪŋ, dʒʌs tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə ɹɛst. feɪl dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt ðə wʊmən wəɾ ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ ə spaɪ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u dɪd nɑt tɔk fɹili ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hɝd, ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊl bæk əɹ bɑɹɡən, feɪst ən ənsɝɾən fjutʃɝ, pɑsəbli ɛndɪŋ ɪn ə ʃæloʊ ɡɹeɪv.

Sooner or later Sevanna herself was going to learn that Wise Ones were stopping her gai'shain to question them. Sevanna had well over a hundred servants and kept adding to them, and Faile was certain that every last one was repeating every word they heard Sevanna say to the Wise Ones. It was a brutally efficient trap. Sevanna was a harsh mistress, in a rather casual way, never snapping, seldom openly angry, but the slightest infraction, the smallest slip in demeanor or behavior, was punished immediately with the switch or the strap, and every night the five gai'shain who had pleased her least that day were chosen out for further punishment, sometimes a night bound and gagged on top of a beating, just to encourage the rest. Faile did not want to think of what the woman would order for a spy. On the other hand, the Wise Ones had made it clear that anyone who did not talk freely of what they heard, anyone who tried to hold back or bargain, faced an uncertain future, possibly ending in a shallow grave.

hɑɹmɪŋ ə ɡeɪʃeɪn bɪɑn ðə pɝmɪɾəd lɪməts ə dɪsəplən wɑz ə vaɪəleɪʃən ə dʒiɾoʊ, ðə wɛb ʌv ɑnɝ ən ɑbləɡeɪʃən ðət ɡʌvɝn ðə laɪvz ʌv il, bʌt wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn sim tə stæn aʊtsaɪɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə ɹulz.

Harming a gai'shain beyond the permitted limits of discipline was a violation of ji'e'toh, the web of honor and obligation that governed the lives of Aiel, but wetlander gai'shain seemed to stand outside a number of the rules.

sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, wʌn saɪɾ əɹ ði ʌðɝ ə ðət tʃɹæp wəd snæp ʃʌt. ɔl ðət hæd hɛl ðə dʒɔz əpɑɹt ðɪs lɔŋ wɑz ðət ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sim tə si ðɛɹ wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn əz noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm kɑɹt hɔɹsəz əɹ pæk ænəməlz, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ ði ænəməlz ɹəsiv fɑɹ bɛɾɝ tʃɹitmənt. naʊ ən ðən ə ɡeɪʃeɪn tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn əweɪ, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, wʌn sɪmpli ɡeɪv əm fuɾ ən ʃɛltɝ, pʊɾ əm tə wɝk ən pʌnɪʃt əm ɪf ðeɪ fɔltɝd. ðə waɪz wʌnz noʊ mɔɹ ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə dɪsəbeɪ, sɪvænə noʊ mɔɹ ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə spaɪ ɑn hɝ, ðən ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə kɑɹt hɔɹs tə sɪŋ. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ. . . . ən ðət wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli tʃɹæp feɪl wɑz kɑɾ ɪn.

Sooner or later, one side or the other of that trap would snap shut. All that had held the jaws apart this long was that the Shaido seemed to see their wetlander gai'shain as no different from cart horses or pack animals, though in truth the animals received far better treatment. Now and then a gai'shain tried to run away, but aside from that, one simply gave them food and shelter, put them to work and punished them if they faltered. The Wise Ones no more expected them to disobey, Sevanna no more expected them to spy on her, than they expected a cart horse to sing. Sooner or later, though. . . . And that was not the only trap Faile was caught in.

"waɪz wʌn, aɪ hæv nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ tə tɛl," ʃi mɝmɝd wən sʌmɛɝɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ənlɛs jə wɝ æɾəld ɪn ðə hɛd, jə dɪd nɑt dʒʌst wɔk əweɪ fɹəm ə waɪz wʌn, nɑɾ əntɪl ʃi dɪsmɪs ju. "ðə waɪz wʌn sɪvænə tɔks fɹili ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌs, bʌt ʃi sɛz lɪɾəl." ðə tɔl wʊmən ɹɪmeɪn saɪlənt, ən æftɝ ə lɔŋ moʊmən feɪl dɛɹd tə ɹeɪz əɹ aɪz ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. sʌmɛɝɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ oʊvɝ feɪlz hɛd, hɝ maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən ɪn stʌn əmeɪzmənt.

"Wise One, I have nothing more to tell," she murmured when Someryn said nothing. Unless you were addled in the head, you did not just walk away from a Wise One, not until she dismissed you. "The Wise One Sevanna talks freely in front of us, but she says little." The tall woman remained silent, and after a long moment Faile dared to raise her eyes a little more. Someryn was staring over Faile's head, her mouth hanging open in stunned amazement.

fɹaʊnɪŋ, feɪl ʃɪftəd ðə bæskəɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən lʊk bɪhaɪn hɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə əkaʊn fəɹ sʌmɛɝɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən, dʒʌs ðə spɹɔl ə ðə kæmp, dɑɹk loʊ il tɛns mɪŋɡəld wɪð pik tɛns ən wɔl tɛns ən ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə tɛnt, moʊst ɪn ʃeɪdz ə dɝɾi waɪɾ əɹ peɪl bɹaʊn, ʌðɝz ɡɹin əɹ blu əɹ ɹɛɾ əɹ ivən stʃɹaɪpt. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʊk ɛvɹiθɪŋ væljəbəl wən ðeɪ stʃɹʌk, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət maɪt pɹuv jusfəl, ən ðeɪ lɛf bɪhaɪnd nʌθɪŋ ðət ɹɪzɛmbəld ə tɛnt.

Frowning, Faile shifted the basket on her shoulder and looked behind her, but there was nothing to account for Someryn's expression, just the sprawl of the camp, dark low Aiel tents mingled with peaked tents and walled tents and every sort of tent, most in shades of dirty white or pale brown, others green or blue or red or even striped. The Shaido took everything valuable when they struck, everything that might prove useful, and they left behind nothing that resembled a tent.

əz ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ hɑɹdli hæɾ ɪnʌf ʃɛltɝ tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ tɛn sɛps ɡæðɝd hɪɹ, mɔɹ ðən sɛvənti θaʊzənd ʃeɪɾoʊ ən nɪɹli əz mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn, baɪ hɝ ɛstəmət, ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ ʃi sɔ oʊnli ðə juʒəwəl bʌsəl, dɑɹk-klæɾ il ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ laɪvz əmʌŋ skɝiɪŋ waɪt-klæd kæptɪvz. ə smɪθ wɑz wɝkɪŋ ðə bɛloʊz ɑn ɪz fɔɹdʒ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ən oʊpən tɛnt wɪð ɪz tulz leɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn ə tæn bʊl haɪd, tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ hɝɾɪŋ flɑks ə bliɾɪŋ ɡoʊts wɪð swɪtʃəz, ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ wɑz dɪspleɪɪŋ əɹ ɡʊdz ɪn ən oʊpən pəvɪljən ə jɛloʊ kænvəs, ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm ɡoʊldən kændəlstɪks ən sɪlvɝ boʊlz tə pɑts ən kɛɾəlz, ɔl luɾəd. ə lin mæn wɪð ə hɔɹs ɑn ə lɛd stʊd tɔkɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd waɪz wʌn neɪmd mæsəlɪn, noʊ daʊt sikɪŋ ə kjʊɹ fəɹ səm eɪlmən ði ænəməl hæd, fɹəm ðə weɪ hi kɛpt pɔɪntɪŋ ət ðə hɔɹsəz bɛli. nʌθɪŋ tə meɪk sʌmɛɝɪn ɡeɪp.

As it was, they hardly had enough shelter to go around. There were ten septs gathered here, more than seventy thousand Shaido and nearly as many gai'shain, by her estimate, and everywhere she saw only the usual bustle, dark-clad Aiel going about their lives among scurrying white-clad captives. A smith was working the bellows on his forge in front of an open tent with his tools laid out on a tanned bull hide, children were herding flocks of bleating goats with switches, a trader was displaying her goods in an open pavilion of yellow canvas, everything from golden candlesticks and silver bowls to pots and kettles, all looted. A lean man with a horse on a lead stood talking with a gray-haired Wise One named Masalin, no doubt seeking a cure for some ailment the animal had, from the way he kept pointing at the horse's belly. Nothing to make Someryn gape.

dʒʌst əz feɪl wɑz əbaʊt tə tɝn bæk ɝaʊnd, ʃi noʊɾəst ə dɑɹkhɛɹɾ il wʊmən feɪsɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ. nɑt dʒʌs dɑɹk hɛɹ, bʌt hɛɹ blæk əz ə ɹeɪvənz wɪŋ, ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɛɹəɾi əmʌŋ il. ivən fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, feɪl θɔt ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əlɹiz, ənʌðɝ ə ðə waɪz wʌnz. ðəɹ wɝ oʊvɝ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd waɪz wʌnz ɪn ðə kæmp, bʌt ʃi hæd lɝn kwɪkli tə noʊ ɔl ə ðɛm ɑn saɪt. mɪsteɪkɪŋ ə waɪz wʌn fəɹ ə wivɝ əɹ ə pɑɾɝ wɑz ə kwɪk weɪ tə ɝn ə swɪtʃɪŋ.

Just as Faile was about to turn back around, she noticed a darkhaired Aiel woman facing the other way. Not just dark hair, but hair black as a raven's wing, a great rarity among Aiel. Even from behind, Faile thought she recognized Alarys, another of the Wise Ones. There were over four hundred Wise Ones in the camp, but she had learned quickly to know all of them on sight. Mistaking a Wise One for a weaver or a potter was a quick way to earn a switching.

ɪt maɪɾ əv mɛnt nʌθɪŋ ðəɾ əlɹiz wɑz stændɪŋ stɑk stɪl ən lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən əz sʌmɛɝɪn, əɹ ðət ʃi hæd lɛɾ əɹ ʃɔl slaɪd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɪksɛp ðət dʒʌs bɪɑn hɝ, feɪl ɹɛkəɡnaɪz stɪl ənʌðɝ waɪz wʌn, ɔlsoʊ lʊkɪŋ ɔf tə ðə nɔɹθ ən wɛst, ən slæpɪŋ ət pipəl u wɔkt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ðət hæd tə bi dʒəsən, ə wʊmən u wʊɾə bɪn kɔld ʃɔɹɾ ivən ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑɾ il, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt mæs ə hɛɹ ɹɛɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk faɪɝ lʊk peɪl ən ə tɛmpɝ tə mætʃ.

It might have meant nothing that Alarys was standing stock still and looking in the same direction as Someryn, or that she had let her shawl slide to the ground, except that just beyond her, Faile recognized still another Wise One, also looking off to the north and west, and slapping at people who walked in front of her. That had to be Jesain, a woman who would have been called short even if she were not Aiel, with a great mass of hair red enough to make fire look pale and a temper to match.

mæsəlɪn wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə ðə mæn wɪð ðə hɔɹs ən dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ tə ði ænəməl. ʃi kəd nɑt tʃænəl, bʌt θɹi waɪz wʌnz u kəd wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ kəɾ əkaʊn fəɹ ɪt; ðeɪ sɔ sʌmwʌn tʃænəlɪŋ ʌp ðəɹ ɑn ðə fɔɹəstəd ɹɪdʒəlaɪn bɪɑn ðə kæmp. eɪ waɪz wʌn tʃænəlɪŋ ʃʊɹli wəd nɑt meɪk ɛni ʌv əm stɛɹ. kəɾ ɪt bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? əɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn?

Masalin was talking to the man with the horse and gesturing to the animal. She could not channel, but three Wise Ones who could were all staring in the same direction. Only one thing could account for it; they saw someone channeling up there on the forested ridgeline beyond the camp. A Wise One channeling surely would not make any of them stare. Could it be an Aes Sedai? Or more than one?

bɛɾɝ nɑt tə ɡɛɾ əɹ hoʊps ʌp. ɪt wɑz tu sun.

Better not to get her hopes up. It was too soon.

ə klaʊɾ ɑn ðə hɛd stæɡɝd hɝ, ən ʃi nɪɹli dʒɹɑp ðə bæskət. "waɪ ɑɹ jə stændɪŋ laɪk ə lʌmp?" sʌmɛɝɪn snɑɹəld. "ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð jəɹ wɝk. ɡoʊ, bɪfɔɹ aɪ . . . !" feɪl wɛnt, bælənsɪŋ ðə bæskət wɪð wʌn hænd, lɪftɪŋ ðə skɝts ə hɝ ɹoʊb aʊɾ ə ðə mʌɾi snoʊ wɪð ði ʌðɝ, ən muvɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz ʃi kəd wɪθaʊt slɪpɪŋ ən fɔlɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌk.

A clout on the head staggered her, and she nearly dropped the basket. "Why are you standing like a lump?" Someryn snarled. "Go on with your work. Go, before I . . . !" Faile went, balancing the basket with one hand, lifting the skirts of her robe out of the muddy snow with the other, and moving as quickly as she could without slipping and falling in the muck.

sʌmɛɝɪn nɛvɝ hɪɾ ɛniwʌn, ən ʃi nɛvɝ ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs. ɪf ʃi wɑz duɪŋ boʊθ, ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bi aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ wɪð noʊ dɪleɪ. hʌmbli ən oʊbiɾiəntli.

Someryn never hit anyone, and she never raised her voice. If she was doing both, it was best to be out of her way with no delay. Humbly and obediently.

pɹaɪd sɛd tə meɪnteɪn ə kul dɪfaɪəns, ə kwaɪət ɹəfjuzəl tə jild, jɛt sɛns sɛd ðət wɑz ðə weɪ tə faɪn hɝsɛlf ɡɑɹɾəd twaɪs əz kloʊsli əz ʃi wɑz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ maɪt teɪk ðə wɛtləndɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn fəɹ dəmɛstəkeɪɾəd ænəməlz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt kəmplitli blaɪnd. ðeɪ mʌs θɪŋk ðət ʃi hæɾ æksɛptɪɾ əɹ kæptɪvəɾi əz ɪnɪskeɪpəbəl ɪf ʃi wɝ tə bi eɪbəl tə ɪskeɪp, ən ðət wɑz vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɑn əɹ maɪnd. ðə sunɝ, ðə bɛɾɝ. sɝɾənli bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn kɑɾ ʌp. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ daʊɾɪd ðət pɛɹɪn wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, ðəɾ i wəd faɪn əɹ sʌmhaʊ - ðə mæn wəd wɔk θɹu ə wɔl ɪf i tʊk ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz hɛd! -  bʌt ʃi hæd tə ɪskeɪp bɪfɔɹ ðæt. ʃi wɑz ə soʊlʒɝz dɔɾɝ. ʃi nu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz nʌmbɝz, ʃi nu ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ pɛɹɪn hæd tə kɔl ɑn, ən ʃi nu ʃi hæd tə ɹitʃ ɪm bɪfɔɹ ðət klæʃ kəd teɪk pleɪs. ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌs ðə lɪɾəl mæɾɝ ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, fɝst.

Pride said to maintain a cool defiance, a quiet refusal to yield, yet sense said that was the way to find herself guarded twice as closely as she was. The Shaido might take the wetlander gai'shain for domesticated animals, but they were not completely blind. They must think that she had accepted her captivity as inescapable if she were to be able to escape, and that was very much on her mind. The sooner, the better. Certainly before Perrin caught up. She had never doubted that Perrin was following her, that he would find her somehow - the man would walk through a wall if he took it into his head! -  but she had to escape before that. She was a soldier's daughter. She knew the Shaido's numbers, she knew the strength Perrin had to call on, and she knew she had to reach him before that clash could take place. There was just the little matter of getting free of the Shaido, first.

wʌt hæd ðə waɪz wʌnz bɪn lʊkɪŋ ət - ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ waɪz wʌnz wɪð pɛɹɪn? laɪt, ʃi hoʊp nɑt, nɑt jɛt! bʌɾ ʌðɝ mæɾɝz tʊk pɹɛsəɾəns, ðə lɔnʒɹi nɑt list. ʃi kæɹid ðə bæskət təwɔɹd wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə sɪɾi ʌv meɪɾən, wivɪŋ θɹu ə stɛɾi floʊ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðoʊz livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi itʃ kæɹiɾ ə pɛɹ ə hɛvi bʌkəts bælənst ɑn ði ɛnz ʌv ə poʊl kæɹiɾ əkɹɔs ðə ʃoʊldɝz, waɪl ðə bʌkəts ə ðoʊz ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn sweɪd, ɛmpti, ɑn ðɛɹ poʊlz. əz mɛni pipəl əz wɝ ɪn ðə kæmp ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv wɔɾɝ, ən ðɪs wɑz haʊ ɪt keɪm tə ðɛm, bʌkət baɪ bʌkət.

What had the Wise Ones been looking at - the Aes Sedai or Wise Ones with Perrin? Light, she hoped not, not yet! But other matters took precedence, the laundry not least.
