She carried the basket toward what remained of the city of Maiden, weaving through a steady flow of gai'shain. Those leaving the city each carried a pair of heavy buckets balanced on the ends of a pole carried across the shoulders, while the buckets of those going in swayed, empty, on their poles. As many people as were in the camp required a great deal of water, and this was how it came to them, bucket by bucket.

ɪt wɑz izi tə tɛl ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn u hæd bɪn ɪnhæbəɾənts ə meɪɾən. ðɪs fɑɹ nɔɹθ ɪn ɔltɑɹə, ðeɪ wɝ fɛɹ ɹæðɝ ðən oʊlɪvɪkəmplɛktɪd, ən səm ivən hæd blu aɪz, bʌɾ ɔl stʌmbəld əlɔŋ ɪn ə deɪz. ʃeɪɾoʊ klaɪmɪŋ ðə sɪɾi wɔlz ɪn ðə naɪt hæɾ oʊvɝwɛlm ðə dɪfɛnsəz bɪfɔɹ moʊst ə ðə ɹɛzəɾənts nu ðeɪ wɝ ɪn deɪnʒɝ, ən ðeɪ stɪl simd əneɪbəl tə bɪliv wʌt ðɛɹ laɪvz hæd kʌm tə.

It was easy to tell the gai'shain who had been inhabitants of Maiden. This far north in Altara, they were fair rather than olivecomplected, and some even had blue eyes, but all stumbled along in a daze. Shaido climbing the city walls in the night had overwhelmed the defenses before most of the residents knew they were in danger, and they still seemed unable to believe what their lives had come to.

feɪl sɝtʃt fəɹ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ feɪs, ðoʊ, sʌmwʌn ʃi hoʊpt wəd nɑt bi kæɹiɪŋ wɔɾɝ tədeɪ. ʃi hæd bɪn lʊkɪŋ ɛvɝ sɪns ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ meɪd kæmp hɪɹ, fɔɹ deɪz əɡoʊ. dʒʌst aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪts, wɪtʃ stʊɾ oʊpən ən ʃʌv bæk əɡɛns ðə ɡɹænət wɔlz, ʃi faʊn hɝ, ə waɪt-klæd wʊmən tɔlɝ ðən hɝsɛlf wɪð ə flæt bæskəɾ ə bɹɛɾ ɑn əɹ hɪp ən əɹ hʊd pʊʃt bæk dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ə bɪɾ ə dɑɹk ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ. kiæɾ əpɪɹd tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ɡeɪts ðət hæd feɪl tə pɹətɛk meɪɾən, bʌt ʃi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm əm əz sun əz feɪl əpɹoʊtʃt. ðeɪ pɔz saɪd baɪ saɪd, nɑt ɹɪli lʊkɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ waɪl ðeɪ pɹitɛndəd tə ʃɪf ðɛɹ bæskəts. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən tu ɡeɪʃeɪn ʃəd nɑt tɔk tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, bʌt noʊ wʌn ʃəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd təɡɛðɝ. beɪn ən kiæd wɝ nɑt wɑtʃt əz kloʊsli əz ɡeɪʃeɪn sɝvɪŋ sɪvænə, bʌt ðət maɪt tʃeɪnʒ ɪf ɛniwʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt wɑz ɡeɪʃeɪn, ən fɹəm wɛst ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl bɪsaɪdz, jɛt tu mɛni hæd lɝn tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ baɪ kæɹiɪŋ teɪlz ən ɹumɝz. moʊs pipəl dɪd wʌt ðeɪ mʌs tə sɝvaɪv, ən səm ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə fɛðɝ ðɛɹ oʊn nɛsts, wʌtɛvɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz.

Faile searched for a particular face, though, someone she hoped would not be carrying water today. She had been looking ever since the Shaido made camp here, four days ago. Just outside the city gates, which stood open and shoved back against the granite walls, she found her, a white-clad woman taller than herself with a flat basket of bread on her hip and her hood pushed back just enough to show a bit of dark reddish hair. Chiad appeared to be studying the iron-strapped gates that had failed to protect Maiden, but she turned away from them as soon as Faile approached. They paused side by side, not really looking at one another while they pretended to shift their baskets. There was no reason two gai'shain should not talk to one another, but no one should remember that they had been captured together. Bain and Chiad were not watched as closely as gai'shain serving Sevanna, but that might change if anyone remembered. Almost everyone in sight was gai'shain, and from west of the Dragonwall besides, yet too many had learned to curry favor by carrying tales and rumors. Most people did what they must to survive, and some always tried to feather their own nests, whatever the circumstances.

"ðeɪ ɡɑɾ əweɪ ðə fɝs naɪt hɪɹ," kiæd mɝmɝd. "beɪn ən aɪ lɛɾ əm aʊt tə ðə tʃɹiz ən əbskjʊɹd ðə tʃɹæks kʌmɪŋ bæk. noʊ wʌn simz tə ɹilaɪz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɔn, əz fɑɹ əz aɪ kən si.

"They got away the first night here," Chiad murmured. "Bain and I led them out to the trees and obscured the tracks coming back. No one seems to realize they are gone, as far as I can see.

wɪð soʊ mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn, ɪt simz ə wʌndɝ ðiz ʃeɪɾoʊ noʊɾəs ɛni hu ɹʌn əweɪ." feɪl hivd ə smɔl saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. θɹi deɪz ɡɔn. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪd noʊɾəs ɹʌnəweɪz. fju mænədʒd ə fʊl deɪ ʌv fɹiɾəm, bʌt ðə tʃænsəz ə səksɛs ɪnkɹist wɪð ɛvɹi deɪ ənkɔt, ən ɪt sim sɝɾən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wəd muv ɑn təmɑɹoʊ, əɹ ðə nɛks deɪ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt hɔltəɾ əz lɔŋ əz ðɪs sɪns feɪl wɑz kæptʃɝd. ʃi səspɛktəd ðeɪ maɪt bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mɑɹtʃ bæk tə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl ən ɹɛkɹɔs ɪndə ðə weɪst.

With so many gai'shain, it seems a wonder these Shaido notice any who run away." Faile heaved a small sigh of relief. Three days gone. The Shaido did notice runaways. Few managed a full day of freedom, but the chances of success increased with every day uncaught, and it seemed certain the Shaido would move on tomorrow, or the next day. They had not halted as long as this since Faile was captured. She suspected they might be trying to march back to the Dragonwall and recross into the Waste.

ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn izi tɔkɪŋ lətʃəl ən ɹɛlə ɪndə livɪŋ wɪθaʊt hɝ. wʌt faɪnəli kənvɪnst əm hæd bɪn ði ɑɹɡjəmən ðət ðeɪ kəd kæɹi wɝd tə pɛɹɪn ʌv wɛɹ feɪl wɑz, əlɔŋ wɪð ə wɔɹnɪŋ ə haʊ mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ ðəɹ wɝ ən ə kleɪm ðət feɪl ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɪskeɪp wɛl ɪn hæn ən ɛni ɪntɝfɪɹəns baɪ hɪm maɪɾ ɛndeɪnʒɝ ðəɾ ən hɝ. ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd meɪɾ əm bɪliv ɔl ə ðət - ʃi dɪɾ əv əɹ ɪskeɪp ɪn hænd, ɪn ə weɪ; ʃi hæd sɛvɹəl plænz, ɪn fækt, ən wʌn ə ðɛm hæd tə wɝk - bʌɾ əntɪl ðɪs mɪnət ʃi hæd bɪn hæf kənvɪns ðə tu wɪmən wəd dɪsaɪd ðɛɹ oʊðz tə hɝ ɹikwaɪɝɾ əm tə steɪ. wɔɾɝ oʊðz wɝ taɪɾɝ ðən oʊðz ə fiəlti ɪn səm weɪz, jɛt ðeɪ lɛf kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɹum fəɹ stupɪɾɪti ɪn ðə neɪm ʌv ɑnɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ ðə pɛɹ kəd faɪn pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ iðɝ weɪ, ðeɪ wɝ fɹi ən ʃi hæɾ oʊnli tu ʌðɝ wɪmən tə wɝi əbaʊt. ʌv kɔɹs, ði æbsəns ə θɹi ʌv sɪvænəz sɝvəns wəd bi noʊɾəst vɛɹi kwɪkli, wɪðɪn aʊɝz, ən ðə bɛs tʃɹækɝz wəd bi sɛn tə bɹɪŋ əm bæk. feɪl wɑz əkʌstəm tə ðə wʊdz, bʌt ʃi nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə pɪt hɝsɛlf əɡɛnst il tʃɹækɝz. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi ənplɛzən fəɹ "ɔɹɾənɛɹi" ɡeɪʃeɪn u ɹæn əweɪ ən wɝ ɹikæptʃɝd. fəɹ sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn, ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ tə daɪ ɪn ði ətɛmpt. ət bɛst, ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ bi əlaʊd ði ɑpɝtunəɾi fəɹ ə sɛkən tʃɹaɪ.

It had not been easy talking Lacile and Arrela into leaving without her. What finally convinced them had been the argument that they could carry word to Perrin of where Faile was, along with a warning of how many Shaido there were and a claim that Faile already had her own escape well in hand and any interference by him might endanger that and her. She was sure she had made them believe all of that - she did have her escape in hand, in a way; she had several plans, in fact, and one of them had to work - but until this minute she had been half convinced the two women would decide their oaths to her required them to stay. Water oaths were tighter than oaths of fealty in some ways, yet they left considerable room for stupidity in the name of honor. In truth, she did not know whether the pair could find Perrin, but either way, they were free and she had only two other women to worry about. Of course, the absence of three of Sevanna's servants would be noticed very quickly, within hours, and the best trackers would be sent to bring them back. Faile was accustomed to the woods, but she knew better than to pit herself against Aiel trackers. It was very unpleasant for "ordinary" gai'shain who ran away and were recaptured. For Sevanna's gai'shain, it might be better to die in the attempt. At best, they would never be allowed the opportunity for a second try.

"ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs wəɾ əv ə bɛɾɝ tʃæns ɪf jə ən beɪn keɪm wɪð ʌs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. ðə floʊ ʌv mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn waɪt kæɹiɪŋ wɔɾɝ baɪ ðɛm kəntɪnjud, noʊ wʌn simɪŋ tə mɔɹ ðən ɡlæns ðɛɹ weɪ, bʌt wɛɹinɪs hæd bɪkʌm ɪnɡɹeɪn ɪn əɹ ðiz læs tu wiks. laɪt, ɪt simd mɔɹ laɪk tu jɪɹz! "wʌt dɪfɝəns kən ðəɹ bi bɪtwin hɛlpɪŋ lətʃəl ən ɹɛlə ɹitʃ ðə fɔɹəst ən hɛlpɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs ɡɛt fɝðɝ?" ðət wɑz dɪspɛɹ tɔkɪŋ. ʃi nu ðə dɪfɝəns - beɪn ən kiæd wɝ əɹ fɹɛnz ən hæd tɔɾ əɹ əbaʊɾ il weɪz, əbaʊt dʒiɾoʊ ən ivən ə lɪɾəl meɪɾən hæntɔk - ən ɪt dɪd nɑt sɝpɹaɪz əɹ wən kiæd tɝn əɹ hɛd slaɪtli tə ɹəɡɑɹɾ əɹ wɪð ɡɹeɪ aɪz ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn miknəs ɪn ðɛm. nɔɹ dɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs, ðoʊ ʃi stɪl spoʊk kwaɪətli.

"The rest of us would have a better chance if you and Bain came with us," she said in a low voice. The flow of men and women in white carrying water by them continued, no one seeming to more than glance their way, but wariness had become ingrained in her these last two weeks. Light, it seemed more like two years! "What difference can there be between helping Lacile and Arrela reach the forest and helping the rest of us get further?" That was despair talking. She knew the difference - Bain and Chiad were her friends and had taught her about Aiel ways, about ji'e'toh and even a little Maiden handtalk - and it did not surprise her when Chiad turned her head slightly to regard her with gray eyes that had nothing of gai'shain meekness in them. Nor did her voice, though she still spoke quietly.

"aɪ wɪl hɛlp jə əz fɑɹ əz aɪ kən kəz ɪts nɑt ɹaɪt fəɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tə hoʊl ju. jə də nɑt fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ. aɪ du. ɪf aɪ kæst əsaɪd maɪ ɑnɝ ən maɪ ɑbləɡeɪʃənz dʒʌs kəz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæv, ðən aɪ əlaʊ ðɛm tə dɪsaɪd haʊ əl ækt. əl wɛɹ waɪt fəɹ ə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ ən ðən ðəl ɹilis mi, əɹ əl wɔk əweɪ, bʌɾ əl nɑt θɹoʊ əweɪ hu aɪ æm." wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd, kiæd stʃɹoʊɾ ɔf ɪndə ðə θɹɔŋz ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn.

"I will help you as far as I can because it is not right for the Shaido to hold you. You do not follow ji'e'toh. I do. If I cast aside my honor and my obligations just because the Shaido have, then I allow them to decide how I will act. I will wear white for a year and a day and then they will release me, or I will walk away, but I will not throw away who I am." Without another word, Chiad strode off into the throngs of gai'shain.

feɪl hæf-ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə stɑp hɝ, ðən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl. ʃi hæɾ æsk ðət kwɛstʃən bɪfɔɹ, ɹəsivɪŋ ə dʒɛnlɝ ænsɝ, ən ɪn æskɪŋ əɡɛn, ʃi hæɾ ɪnsʌltɪɾ əɹ fɹɛnd. ʃi wəɾ əv tə əpɑlədʒaɪz. nɑt tə kip kiædz hɛlp - ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt wɪðdʒɹɔ ðət - bʌt kəz ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɑnɝ, ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ. jə dɪd nɑɾ ɪnsʌl fɹɛnz ən sɪmpli fɝɡɛɾ ɪt, əɹ ɪkspɛkt əm tə. əpɑlədʒiz mʌst weɪt, ðoʊ. ðeɪ dɛɹd nɑt bi sin tɔkɪŋ tu lɔŋ.

Faile half-raised a hand to stop her, then let it fall. She had asked that question before, receiving a gentler answer, and in asking again, she had insulted her friend. She would have to apologize. Not to keep Chiad's help - the woman would not withdraw that - but because she had her own honor, even if she did not follow ji'e'toh. You did not insult friends and simply forget it, or expect them to. Apologies must wait, though. They dared not be seen talking too long.

meɪɾən hæd bɪn ə pɹɑspɝəs sɪɾi, ə pɹədusɝ ʌv ɡʊd wʊl ən ɡɹeɪt kwɑntəɾiz ə fɛɹ-kwɑləɾi waɪn, bʌɾ ən ɛmpti ɹuən ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, naʊ. əz mɛni ʌv ðə sleɪt-ɹuf haʊsəz wɝ tɪmbɝ əz wɝ stoʊn, ən faɪɝ hæd ɡɑɾən lus dʊɹɪŋ ðə luɾɪŋ. ðə sʌðɝn ɛn ə ðə sɪɾi wɑz hæf paɪlz ə blækən tɪmbɝz dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð aɪsɪkəlz, hæf skɔɹtʃt, ɹufləs wɔlz. ðə stʃɹits ɛvɹiwɛɹ, wɛðɝ stoʊn-peɪvd əɹ dɝt, wɝ ɡɹeɪ wɪð wɪnbloʊn æʃ tʃɹæmpəld ɪndə ðə snoʊ, ən ðə hoʊl sɪɾi stæŋk ə tʃɑɹd wʊd. wɔɾɝ wɑz wʌn θɪŋ meɪɾən əpɛɹənli nɛvɝ ɹæn ʃɔɹɾ ʌv, bʌt laɪk ɔl il, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ pleɪst ə vɛɹi haɪ vælju ɑn ɪt, ən ðeɪ nu nʌθɪŋ ə faɪɾɪŋ faɪɝz. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ɪn ði il weɪs ðət kəd bɝn. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv lɛt ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi bi kənsum hæd ðeɪ bɪn fɪnɪʃt wɪð stilɪŋ, ən əz ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ dɪðɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə weɪst ʌv wɔɾɝ bɪfɔɹ fɔɹsɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪndə bʌkət laɪnz ət spɪɹpɔɪn ən lɛɾɪŋ ðə mɛn ə meɪɾən bɹɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ pʌmpwæɡənz.

Maiden had been a prosperous city, a producer of good wool and great quantities of fair-quality wine, but an empty ruin inside the walls, now. As many of the slate-roofed houses were timber as were stone, and fire had gotten loose during the looting. The southern end of the city was half piles of blackened timbers decorated with icicles, half scorched, roofless walls. The streets everywhere, whether stone-paved or dirt, were gray with windblown ash trampled into the snow, and the whole city stank of charred wood. Water was one thing Maiden apparently never ran short of, but like all Aiel, the Shaido placed a very high value on it, and they knew nothing of fighting fires. There was little in the Aiel Waste that could burn. They might have let the entire city be consumed had they been finished with stealing, and as it was, they dithered over the waste of water before forcing gai'shain into bucket lines at spearpoint and letting the men of Maiden bring out their pumpwagons.

feɪl wʊɾə θɔt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wəɾ ət list əv ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd ðoʊz mɛn baɪ əlaʊɪŋ əm tə liv wɪð ðə pipəl u hæɾ ɪskeɪp biɪŋ tʃoʊzən fəɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn, bʌt ðə mɛn u wɝk ðə pʌmps wɝ jʌŋ ən fɪt, dʒʌs ðə sɔɹt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɑntəd fəɹ ðɛɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kɛp səm ə ðə ɹulz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn - wɪmən u wɝ pɹɛɡnən əɹ hæd tʃɪlʒɹən ʌndɝ ði eɪdʒ ɔfən hæd bɪn lɛt ɡoʊ, ən juðz ʌndɝ sɪkstin, ən ðə sɪɾiz blæksmɪθs, hu hæd bɪn boʊθ mɪstəfaɪɾ ən ɡɹeɪtfəl -  bʌt ɡɹæɾətud nɛvɝ ɛntɝɾ ɪndə ɪt.

Faile would have thought the Shaido would at least have rewarded those men by allowing them to leave with the people who had escaped being chosen for gai'shain, but the men who worked the pumps were young and fit, just the sort the Shaido wanted for their gai'shain. The Shaido kept some of the rules regarding gai'shain - women who were pregnant or had children under the age often had been let go, and youths under sixteen, and the city's blacksmiths, who had been both mystified and grateful -  but gratitude never entered into it.

fɝnɪtʃɝ lɪɾɝd ðə stʃɹits, lɑɹdʒ oʊvɝtɝn teɪbəlz ən ɔɹneɪt tʃɛsts ən tʃɛɹz, ən səmtaɪmz ə kɹʌmpəld wɔl hæŋɪŋ əɹ bɹoʊkən dɪʃəz. bɪts ə kloʊðɪŋ leɪ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz ən dʒɹɛsəz, moʊst slaɪs tə tæɾɝz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd sizd ɛniθɪŋ meɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ, ɛniθɪŋ ðət hæd dʒɛmz, ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl əɹ ɛɾəbəl, bʌt ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz mʌst əv bɪn hɔld aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə fɹɛnzi ʌv luɾɪŋ, ðən əbændənd wən huɛvɝ wɑz kæɹiɪŋ əm dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ ə lɪɾəl ɡɪldɪɾ ɛdʒɪŋ əɹ faɪn kɑɹvɪŋ dɪd nɑt meɪk əm wɝθ ði ɛfɝt. il dɪd nɑt juz tʃɛɹz ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪksɛp fəɹ tʃifs, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹum ɑn ðə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz fəɹ ɛni ʌv ðoʊz hɛvi teɪbəlz. ə fju ʃeɪɾoʊ stɪl wɑndɝd θɹu, sɝtʃɪŋ ðə haʊsəz ən ɪnz ən ʃɑps fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv mɪst, jɛt moʊs pipəl ʃi sɔ wɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts. il hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn sɪɾiz ɪksɛpt əz stɔɹhaʊzəz tə bi plʌndɝd. ə pɛɹ ə meɪɾənz pæs hɝ, juzɪŋ ðə bʌts ə ðɛɹ spɪɹz tə dʒɹaɪv ə neɪkəd, waɪld-aɪd mæn, hɪz ɑɹmz baʊn bɪhaɪn hɪm, təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts. daʊtləs i hæd θɔɾ i kəd haɪɾ ɪn ə beɪsmən əɹ æɾɪk əntɪl ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ɡɔn. daʊtləs ðə meɪɾənz hæd θɔt tə faɪn ə kæʃ ə kɔɪn əɹ pleɪt.

Furniture littered the streets, large overturned tables and ornate chests and chairs, and sometimes a crumpled wall hanging or broken dishes. Bits of clothing lay everywhere, coats and breeches and dresses, most sliced to tatters. The Shaido had seized anything made of gold or silver, anything that had gems, anything useful or edible, but the furnishings must have been hauled outside in the frenzy of looting, then abandoned when whoever was carrying them decided that a little gilded edging or fine carving did not make them worth the effort. Aiel did not use chairs in any case, except for chiefs, and there was no room on the carts and wagons for any of those heavy tables. A few Shaido still wandered through, searching the houses and inns and shops for anything they might have missed, yet most people she saw were gai'shain carrying buckets. Aiel had no interest in cities except as storehouses to be plundered. A pair of Maidens passed her, using the butts of their spears to drive a naked, wild-eyed man, his arms bound behind him, toward the gates. Doubtless he had thought he could hide in a basement or attic until the Shaido were gone. Doubtless the Maidens had thought to find a cache of coin or plate.

wən ə hjudʒ mæn ɪn ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ ʌv ən ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ stɛpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ʃi swɝv tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ɪm əz smuðli əz ʃi kʊd. ə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɔlweɪz meɪd weɪ fəɹ ɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ.

When a huge man in the cadin'sor of an algai'd'siswai stepped in front of her, she swerved to go around him as smoothly as she could. A gai'shain always made way for any Shaido.

"ju ɑɹ vɛɹi pɹɪɾi," hi sɛd, pʊɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn əɹ weɪ. hi wɑz ðə bɪɡəs mæn ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, pɝhæps sɛvən fit tɔl ən θɪk ɪn pɹəpɔɹʃən. nɑt fæt - ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ə fæɾ il - bʌt vɛɹi waɪd. hi bɛltʃt, ən ʃi smɛld waɪn fjumz. dʒɹʌŋkən il ʃi hæd sin, sɪns ðeɪ faʊn ɔl ðoʊz kæsks ʌv waɪn hɪɹ ɪn meɪɾən. ʃi fɛl noʊ fɪɹ, ðoʊ. ɡeɪʃeɪn maɪt bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ ɛni nʌmbɝ ʌv ɪnfɹækʃənz, ɔfən fəɹ tʃɹænzɡɹɛʃənz fju ʌv ðə wɛtləndɝz ʌndɝstʊd, bʌt ðə waɪt ɹoʊbz ɡeɪv ə sɝɾən pɹətɛkʃən, tu, ən ʃi hæɾ ənʌðɝ leɪɝ bɪsaɪdz.

"You are very pretty," he said, putting himself in her way. He was the biggest man she had ever seen, perhaps seven feet tall and thick in proportion. Not fat - she had never seen a fat Aiel - but very wide. He belched, and she smelled wine fumes. Drunken Aiel she had seen, since they found all those casks of wine here in Maiden. She felt no fear, though. Gai'shain might be punished for any number of infractions, often for transgressions few of the wetlanders understood, but the white robes gave a certain protection, too, and she had another layer besides.

"aɪ æm ɡeɪʃeɪn tə ðə waɪz wʌn sɪvænə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn əz əbsikwiəs ə toʊn əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ. tə hɝ dɪsɡʌst, ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən soʊ ʃi kəd mænədʒ ɪt vɛɹi wɛl. "sɪvænə wəd bi dɪsplizd ɪf aɪ ʃɝk maɪ duɾiz tə tɔk." ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɡɛn tə stɛp ɝaʊn hɪm, ən ɡæspt wən i sizd əɹ ɑɹm ɪn ə hæn ðət cʊɾə ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪt twaɪs wɪð ɪntʃəz tə spɛɹ.

"I am gai'shain to the Wise One Sevanna," she said in as obsequious a tone as she could manage. To her disgust, she had gotten so she could manage it very well. "Sevanna would be displeased if I shirked my duties to talk." She tried again to step around him, and gasped when he seized her arm in a hand that could have wrapped around it twice with inches to spare.

"sɪvænə hæz hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn. ʃɪl nɑt mɪs wʌn fəɹ ən aʊɝ əɹ tu." ðə bæskət fɛl tə ðə stʃɹiɾ əz i plʌkt əɹ ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz izəli əz pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə pɪloʊ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, hi hæɾ əɹ tʌk bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹm, hɝ oʊn ɑɹmz tʃɹæpt əɾ əɹ saɪdz.

"Sevanna has hundreds of gai'shain. She will not miss one for an hour or two." The basket fell to the street as he plucked her into the air as easily as picking up a pillow. Before she knew what was happening, he had her tucked beneath his arm, her own arms trapped at her sides.

ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə skɹim, ən i juzd ɪz fɹi hæn tə pɹɛs əɹ feɪs flæɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. ðə smɛl ə swɛɾi wʊl fɪld əɹ noʊz. ɔl ʃi kəd si wɑz ɡɹeɪ-bɹaʊn wʊl. wɛɹ wɝ ðoʊz tu meɪɾənz? meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm də ðɪs! ɛni il u sɔ wəd stɛp ɪn! ʃi nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd hɛlp fɹəm ɛni ʌv ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn. wʌn əɹ tu maɪt ɹʌn fəɹ hɛlp, ɪf ʃi wɑz lʌki, bʌt ðə vɛɹi fɝs lɛsən ə ɡeɪʃeɪn lɝnd wɑz ðəɾ ivən ə θɹɛɾ ə vaɪələns ɡɑt jə hʌŋ ʌp baɪ ði æŋkəlz ən biɾən tɪl jə haʊld. ðə fɝs lɛsən wɛtləndɝz lɝnd, ət list; il ɔlɹɛɾi nu: & ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən tə ɔfɝ vaɪələns fəɹ ɛni ɹizən. ɛni ɹizən. wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt stɑp əɹ fɹəm kɪkɪŋ ət ðə mæn fjʊɹiəsli. ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn kɪkɪŋ ə wɔl fəɹ ɔl ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ɪt meɪd. hi wɑz muvɪŋ, kæɹiɪŋ əɹ sʌmwɛɹ. ʃi bɪɾ əz hɑɹd daʊn əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd, ən ɡɑɾ ə maʊθfʊl ə kɔɹs dɝɾi wʊl fəɹ əɹ peɪnz, hɝ tiθ slaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ mʌsəl wɪð noʊ slæk tə ɡɪv əɹ pɝtʃəs. hi simd meɪɾ ə stoʊn. ʃi skɹimd, bʌɾ əɹ ʃɹik saʊndəd mʌfəld ivən tə hɝ oʊn ɪɹz.

She opened her mouth to scream, and he used his free hand to press her face flat against his chest. The smell of sweaty wool filled her nose. All she could see was gray-brown wool. Where were those two Maidens? Maidens of the Spear would not let him do this! Any Aiel who saw would step in! She never expected help from any of the gai'shain. One or two might run for help, if she was lucky, but the very first lesson a gai'shain learned was that even a threat of violence got you hung up by the ankles and beaten till you howled. The first lesson wetlanders learned, at least; Aiel already knew: & gai'shain was forbidden to offer violence for any reason. Any reason. Which did not stop her from kicking at the man furiously. She might as well have been kicking a wall for all the impression it made. He was moving, carrying her somewhere. She bit as hard down as hard as she could, and got a mouthful of coarse dirty wool for her pains, her teeth sliding over muscle with no slack to give her purchase. He seemed made of stone. She screamed, but her shriek sounded muffled even to her own ears.

əbɹʌpli, ðə mɑnstɝ kæɹiɪŋ əɹ stɑpt.

Abruptly, the monster carrying her stopped.

"aɪ meɪd ðɪs wʌn ɡeɪʃeɪn, nædʒɹɪk," ənʌðɝ mænz dip vɔɪs sɛd.

"I made this one gai'shain, Nadric," another man's deep voice said.

feɪl fɛlt ə ɹʌmbəl ə læftɝ ɪn ðə tʃɛst əɡɛnst əɹ feɪs ivən bɪfɔɹ ʃi hɝɾ ɪt. ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp əɹ kɪkɪŋ, nɛvɝ stɑpt ɹaɪðɪŋ əɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃaʊt, jɛɾ əɹ kæptɝ simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə hɝ ɛfɝts.

Faile felt a rumble of laughter in the chest against her face even before she heard it. She did not stop her kicking, never stopped writhing or trying to shout, yet her captor seemed unaware of her efforts.

"ʃi bɪlɔŋz tə sɪvænə naʊ, bɹʌðɝləs," ðə hjudʒ mæn - nædʒɹɪk? - sɛd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "sɪvænə teɪks wʌt ʃi wɑns, ən aɪ teɪk wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt. ɪts ðə nu weɪ."

"She belongs to Sevanna now, Brotherless," the huge man - Nadric? - said contemptuously. "Sevanna takes what she wants, and I take what I want. It is the new way."

"sɪvænə tʊk hɝ," ði ʌðɝ mæn ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, "bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ ɡeɪv əɹ tə sɪvænə. aɪ nɛvɝ ɔfɝd tə tʃɹeɪɾ əɹ tə sɪvænə. dʒju əbændən jəɹ ɑnɝ kəz sɪvænə əbændənz hɝz?" ðəɹ wɑz ə lɔŋ saɪləns bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ðə smʌðɝd nɔɪzɪz feɪl wɑz meɪkɪŋ. ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ, kəd nɑt stɑp, bʌt ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ən ɪnfən ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ. "ʃi ɪz nɑt pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf tə faɪɾ oʊvɝ," nædʒɹɪk sɛd faɪnəli. hi dɪd nɑt saʊn fɹaɪɾənd əɹ ivən kənsɝnd.

"Sevanna took her," the other man replied calmly, "but I never gave her to Sevanna. I never offered to trade her to Sevanna. Do you abandon your honor because Sevanna abandons hers?" There was a long silence broken only by the smothered noises Faile was making. She did not stop struggling, could not stop, but she might as well have been an infant in swaddling. "She is not pretty enough to fight over," Nadric said finally. He did not sound frightened or even concerned.

hɪz hænz fɛl əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, ən feɪlz tiθ ɹɪp lus fɹəm ɪz koʊt soʊ sʌɾənli ʃi θɔt wʌn əɹ tu maɪt bi dʒɝkt aʊt, bʌt ðə ɡɹaʊn smæʃt ɪndə hɝ bæk ən ɔl ə ði ɛɹ ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ə hɝ lʌŋz əlɔŋ wɪð moʊst ə ðə wɪts fɹəm əɹ hɛd. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi kəd ɡæðɝ ɪnʌf bɹɛθ tə pʊʃ ʌp ɑn əɹ hænz, ðə hjudʒ mæn wɑz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ daʊn ði æli, ɔlmoʊs bæk tə ðə stʃɹit. ɪt wɑz ən æli, ə nɛɹoʊ tʃɹæk ə dɝt bɪtwin tu stoʊn bɪldɪŋz. noʊ wʌn wʊɾə sin wʌɾ i dɪd bæk hɪɹ. ʃɪvɝɪŋ  -  ʃi wɑz nɑt tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, dʒʌst ʃɪvɝɪŋ!  -  spɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðə teɪst ʌv ənwɑʃt wʊl ən nædʒɹɪks swɛt, ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz bæk. ɪf ðə naɪf ʃi hæd hɪɾən əweɪ hæd bɪn wɪðɪn ɹitʃ, ʃi wʊɾə stæb hɪm. nɑt pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf tə faɪɾ oʊvɝ, wɑz ʃi? pɑɹɾ ə hɝ nu ðət wɑz luɾəkɹəs, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡɹæbɪŋ hoʊld ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd fiɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ, dʒʌs fəɹ ðə wɔɹmθ ʌv ɪt. tə hɛlp əɹ stɑp ʃɪvɝɪŋ. ʃi wʊɾə stæbd ɪm ən stæb hɪm, əntɪl ʃi kəd nɑt lɪft əɹ ɑɹmz. ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp ɑn lɛɡz ðət wɑbəld, ʃi ɪksplɔɹɾ əɹ tiθ wɪð əɹ tʌŋ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl saʊnd, nʌθɪŋ bɹoʊkən əɹ mɪsɪŋ. hɝ feɪs hæd bɪn skɹeɪp baɪ ðə ɹʌf wʊl ə nædʒɹɪks koʊt, ən əɹ lɪps wɝ bɹuzd, bʌt ʃi wɑz ənhɝt. ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf ə ðæt. ʃi wɑz ənhɝt, ən fɹi tə wɔk aʊɾ ə ði æli. əz fɹi əz ɛniwʌn ɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz kəd bi, ɛniweɪ. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ mɛni laɪk nædʒɹɪk u noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sɔ ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðoʊz ɹoʊbz, ðən ɔɹɾɝ wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ðə kæmp wəd bi ə mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs, bʌt dɪsɔɹɾɝ wəd bɹɪŋ mɔɹ ɑpɝtunəɾiz fəɹ ɪskeɪp. ðət wɑz haʊ ʃi hæd tə lʊk ət ðɪs. ʃi hæd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ ðət kəɾ eɪd hɝ. ɪf oʊnli ʃi kəd stɑp ʃɪvɝɪŋ.

His hands fell away from her, and Faile's teeth ripped loose from his coat so suddenly she thought one or two might be jerked out, but the ground smashed into her back and all of the air rushed out of her lungs along with most of the wits from her head. By the time she could gather enough breath to push up on her hands, the huge man was striding away down the alley, almost back to the street. It was an alley, a narrow track of dirt between two stone buildings. No one would have seen what he did back here. Shivering  -  she was not trembling, just shivering!  -  spitting out the taste of unwashed wool and Nadric's sweat, she glared at his back. If the knife she had hidden away had been within reach, she would have stabbed him. Not pretty enough to fight over, was she? Part of her knew that was ludicrous, but she was grabbing hold of anything that could feed her anger, just for the warmth of it. To help her stop shivering. She would have stabbed him and stabbed him, until she could not lift her arms. Getting up on legs that wobbled, she explored her teeth with her tongue. They were all sound, nothing broken or missing. Her face had been scraped by the rough wool of Nadric's coat, and her lips were bruised, but she was unhurt. She reminded herself of that. She was unhurt, and free to walk out of the alley. As free as anyone in gai'shain robes could be, anyway. If there were many like Nadric who no longer saw the protection of those robes, then order was breaking down among the Shaido. The camp would be a more dangerous place, but disorder would bring more opportunities for escape. That was how she had to look at this. She had learned something that could aid her. If only she could stop shivering.

ət læst, ɹɪlʌktənli, ʃi lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɹɛskjuɝ. ʃi hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. hi stʊd wɛl bæk fɹəm hɝ, wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ kɑmli, meɪkɪŋ noʊ muv tə ɔfɝ sɪmpəθi. ʃi θɔt ʃi wʊɾə skɹimd ɪf i tʌtʃt hɝ. ənʌðɝ əbsɝɾəti, sɪns i hæd ɹɛskjud hɝ, bʌɾ ə fækt ɔl ðə seɪm. ɹoʊlən wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən nædʒɹɪk, ən ɔlmoʊst əz waɪd, ən ʃi hæd ɹizən tə wɑnə stæb hɪm, tu. hi wɑz nɑt ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌt wʌn ə ðə bɹʌðɝləs, ðə mɛɝeɪɾɪn, mɛn u hæd lɛf ðɛɹ klænz kəz ðeɪ wəd nɑt fɑloʊ ɹænd ælθɹ, ən i hæɾ ɪndid bɪn ðə wʌn tə "meɪk əɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn." tʃɹu, hi hæd kɛpt əɹ fɹəm fɹizɪŋ tə dɛθ ðə naɪɾ æftɝ ʃi wɑz kæptʃɝd baɪ ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɪn ɪz oʊn koʊt, jɛt ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv niɾəd ðə kʌvɝɪŋ ɪf i hæd nɑt kʌɾ ɔf ɛvɹi læst stɪtʃ ə hɝ kloʊðɪŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ðə fɝs pɑɹɾ ə biɪŋ meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz ɔlweɪz biɪŋ stʃɹɪpt, bʌt ðət wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə fɝɡɪv ɪm fəɹ ɛni ʌv ɪt.

At last, reluctantly, she looked at her rescuer. She had recognized his voice. He stood well back from her, watching her calmly, making no move to offer sympathy. She thought she would have screamed if he touched her. Another absurdity, since he had rescued her, but a fact all the same. Rolan was no more than a hand shorter than Nadric, and almost as wide, and she had reason to want to stab him, too. He was not Shaido, but one of the Brotherless, the Mera'din, men who had left their clans because they would not follow Rand al'Thor, and he had indeed been the one to "make her gai'shain." True, he had kept her from freezing to death the night after she was captured by wrapping her in his own coat, yet she would not have needed the covering if he had not cut off every last stitch of her clothing in the first place. The first part of being made gai'shain was always being stripped, but that was no reason to forgive him for any of it.

"θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd, ðə wɝdz saʊɝ ɑn əɹ tʌŋ. "aɪ də nɑɾ æsk fəɹ ɡɹæɾətud," hi sɛd maɪldli.

"Thank you," she said, the words sour on her tongue. "I do not ask for gratitude," he said mildly.

"du nɑt lʊk ət mi əz ðoʊ jə wɑnə baɪt mi dʒʌs kəz jə kəd nɑt baɪt nædʒɹɪk." ʃi mænədʒ nɑt tə snɑɹl əɾ ɪm - bɛɹli; ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv sʌmən miknəs ɹaɪt ðən hæd ʃi wɑntəd tə - bɪfɔɹ ʃi tɝn əweɪ ən stɔk bæk aʊt tə ðə stʃɹit. wɛl, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stɔk. hɝ lɛɡz wɝ stɪl ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ʌv ə lɝtʃ. ðə pæsɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn bɛɹli ɡlænst ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən əz ðeɪ tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ bʌkəts. fju ʌv ðə kæptɪvz wɑntəd tə ʃɛɹ ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz tʃɹʌbəlz. ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnʌf ə ðɛɹ oʊn.

"Do not look at me as though you want to bite me just because you could not bite Nadric." She managed not to snarl at him - barely; she could not have summoned meekness right then had she wanted to - before she turned away and stalked back out to the street. Well, she tried to stalk. Her legs were still shaking enough that it was more of a lurch. The passing gai'shain barely glanced in her direction as they trudged along the street with their water buckets. Few of the captives wanted to share anyone else's troubles. They had enough of their own.

ɹitʃɪŋ ðə lɔnʒɹi bæskət, ʃi ɡeɪv ə saɪ. ɪt leɪ ɑn ɪts saɪd, waɪt sɪlk blaʊsəz ən dɑɹk sɪlk skɝts dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ spɪld aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə dɝɾi æʃ-smɪɹd peɪvmənt. ət list ɪt sim noʊ wʌn hæd tʃɹɑɾən ɑn ðɛm. ɛniwʌn u hæd bɪn kæɹiɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ, ən hæɾ ə deɪ ʌv ɪt tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə, cʊɾə bɪn fɝɡɪvən ɪf ðeɪ feɪl tə stɛp əsaɪd, wɪð bɪts ə kloʊðɪŋ laɪɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn ðət hæd bɪn kʌɾ ɔf ðə pipəl ə meɪɾən u hæd bɪn meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn. ʃi wʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə fɝɡɪv ðɛm.

Reaching the laundry basket, she gave a sigh. It lay on its side, white silk blouses and dark silk skirts divided for riding spilled out over the dirty ash-smeared pavement. At least it seemed no one had trodden on them. Anyone who had been carrying water all morning, and had a day of it to look forward to, could have been forgiven if they failed to step aside, with bits of clothing lying all around that had been cut off the people of Maiden who had been made gai'shain. She would have tried to forgive them.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðə bæskət, ʃi bɪɡæn ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə kloʊðz, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf ðə dɝɾ ən æʃ ðət wəd kʌm lus ən kɛɹfəl nɑt tə ɡɹaɪn ɪn ðə ɹɛst. ənlaɪk sʌmɛɝɪn, sɪvænə hæd teɪkən tə sɪlk. ʃi wɔɹ nʌθɪŋ ɛls.

Righting the basket, she began gathering the clothes, shaking off the dirt and ash that would come loose and careful not to grind in the rest. Unlike Someryn, Sevanna had taken to silk. She wore nothing else.

ʃi wɑz əz pɹaʊɾ ə hɝ sɪlks əz ʃi wɑz ə hɝ dʒuəlɹi, ən ikwəli pəzɛsɪv ə boʊθ. ʃi wəd nɑt bi plizd ɪf ɛni ʌv ðiz ɡɑɹməns feɪl tə bi ɹɪtɝn klin.

She was as proud of her silks as she was of her jewelry, and equally possessive of both. She would not be pleased if any of these garments failed to be returned clean.

əz feɪl leɪd ðə læs blaʊs ətɑp ðə ɹɛst, ɹoʊlən ɹitʃt pæst əɹ ən lɪftəd ðə bæskət wɪð wʌn hænd. ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə snæpɪŋ əɾ ɪm - ʃi kəd kæɹi hɝ oʊn bɝɾənz, θæŋk jə vɛɹi mʌtʃ! - ʃi swɑloʊd ðə wɝdz. hɝ bɹeɪn wɑz ði oʊnli ɹil wɛpən ʃi pəzɛst, ən ʃi hæd tə juz ɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ əɹ tɛmpɝ əv kəntʃɹoʊl. ɹoʊlən hæd nɑt bɪn hɪɹ baɪ tʃæns. ðət wɑz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ kɹɪduləɾi tu fɑɹ.

As Faile laid the last blouse atop the rest, Rolan reached past her and lifted the basket with one hand. On the brink of snapping at him - she could carry her own burdens, thank you very much! - she swallowed the words. Her brain was the only real weapon she possessed, and she had to use it instead of letting her temper have control. Rolan had not been here by chance. That was straining credulity too far.

ʃi hæd sin ɪm fɹikwənli sɪns ʃi wɑz kæptʃɝd, mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɔfən ðən tʃæns kəɾ əkaʊn fɔɹ.

She had seen him frequently since she was captured, much more often than chance could account for.

hi hæd bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ. wʌt wɑz ɪɾ i hæd toʊl nædʒɹɪk? hi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən əɹ tə sɪvænə əɹ ɔfɝd tə tʃɹeɪd hɝ. fəɹ ɔl ðəɾ i hæd bɪn ðə wʌn tə kæptʃɝ hɝ, ʃi θɔɾ i dɪsəpɹuvd ə meɪkɪŋ wɛtləndɝz ɡeɪʃeɪn  - moʊst ə ðə bɹʌðɝləs dɪd - bʌɾ əpɛɹənli hi stɪl kleɪmd ɪz ɹaɪts tə hɝ.

He had been following her. What was it he had told Nadric? He had not given her to Sevanna or offered to trade her. For all that he had been the one to capture her, she thought he disapproved of making wetlanders gai'shain  - most of the Brotherless did - but apparently he still claimed his rights to her.

ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd nɑt nid tə fɪɹ ɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs hɝ. ɹoʊlən hæd hæɾ ɪz tʃæns fəɹ ðæt, wən i hæɾ əɹ neɪkəɾ ən baʊnd, ən i cʊɾə bɪn lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə fɛns poʊs ðɛn. pɝhæps i dɪd nɑt laɪk wɪmən ɪn ðət weɪ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə bɹʌðɝləs wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ aʊtsaɪɾɝz əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ əz ðə wɛtləndɝz. nʌn ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɹɪli tʃɹʌstɪd ðɛm, ən ðə bɹʌðɝləs ðɛmsɛlvz ɔfən sim laɪk mɛn hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz, æksɛptɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kənsɪɾɝd ə lɛsɝ ɹɔŋ ɹæðɝ ðən ɛmbɹeɪs ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹuli ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz lɛsɝ. ɪf ʃi kəd meɪk ə fɹɛn ə ðə mæn, pɝhæps i wəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp hɝ. nɑt tə ɪskeɪp, sɝɾənli - ðət wəɾ æskɪŋ tu mʌtʃ - bʌt. . . .

She was sure she did not need to fear him trying to force her. Rolan had had his chance for that, when he had her naked and bound, and he could have been looking at a fence post then. Perhaps he did not like women in that way. In any case, the Brotherless were almost as much outsiders among the Shaido as the wetlanders. None of the Shaido really trusted them, and the Brotherless themselves often seemed like men holding their noses, accepting what they considered a lesser wrong rather than embrace a greater, but no longer truly sure that it was lesser. If she could make a friend of the man, perhaps he would be willing to help her. Not to escape, certainly - that would asking too much - but. . . .

əɹ wəɾ ɪt? ði oʊnli weɪ tə faɪn aʊt wɑz tə tʃɹaɪ. "θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛn, ən ðɪs taɪm ʃi wɝkt ʌp ə smaɪl. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, hi smaɪl bæk. ə smɔl smaɪl, bɛɹli ðəɹ əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ il wɝ nɑt dɪmɑnstʃɹəɾɪv. ðeɪ kəd sim stoʊn-feɪs tɪl jə bɪkeɪm juz tə ðɛm.

Or would it? The only way to find out was to try. "Thank you," she said again, and this time she worked up a smile. Surprisingly, he smiled back. A small smile, barely there at all, but Aiel were not demonstrative. They could seem stone-faced till you became used to them.

fəɹ ə fju peɪsɪz ðeɪ wɔkt əlɔŋ saɪd baɪ saɪɾ ɪn saɪləns, hɪm kæɹiɪŋ ðə bæskəɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən əɹ hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə skɝts ə hɝ ɹoʊbz. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn aʊt fəɹ ə stʃɹoʊl. ɪf jə skwɪntɪd. səm ə ðə pæsɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn lʊkt əɾ əm ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlweɪz pʊt ðɛɹ aɪz daʊn əɡɛn kwɪkli.

For a few paces they walked along side by side in silence, him carrying the basket in one hand and her holding up the skirts of her robes. They might have been out for a stroll. If you squinted. Some of the passing gai'shain looked at them in surprise, but they always put their eyes down again quickly.

ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ə haʊ tə bɪɡɪn - ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪm tə θɪŋk ʃi wɑz flɝɾɪŋ; hi maɪt laɪk wɪmən æftɝ ɔl - bʌɾ i tʊk əweɪ ðə nəsɛsəɾi.

She could not think of how to begin - she did not want him to think she was flirting; he might like women after all - but he took away the necessity.

"aɪ hæv wɑtʃt ju," hi sɛd. "ju ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ ən fɪɹs, ən nɑɾ əfɹeɪd, aɪ θɪŋk. moʊst ə ðə wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ fɹaɪɾənd hæf aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðeɪ blʌstɝ əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ pʌnɪʃt, ən ðən ðeɪ wip ən kaʊɝ. aɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ ə wʊmən ə mʌtʃ dʒi." "aɪ æm fɹaɪɾənd," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ dʒʌs tʃɹaɪ nɑt lɛɾ ɪt ʃoʊ. kɹaɪɪŋ nɛvɝ dʌz ɛni ɡʊd." moʊs mɛn bɪliv ðæt. tɪɹz kəd ɡɛɾ ɪn jəɹ weɪ ɪf jə lɛt ðɛm, bʌɾ ə fju tɪɹz ʃɛɾ ət naɪt kəd hɛlp jə meɪk ɪt θɹu ðə nɛks deɪ.

"I have watched you," he said. "You are strong and fierce, and not afraid, I think. Most of the wetlanders are frightened half out of their heads. They bluster until they are punished, and then they weep and cower. I think you are a woman of much ji." "I am frightened," she replied. "I just try not let it show. Crying never does any good." Most men believed that. Tears could get in your way if you let them, but a few tears shed at night could help you make it through the next day.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ taɪmz tə wip ən taɪmz tə læf. aɪ wəd laɪk tə si jə læf." ʃi dɪd læf, ə dʒɹaɪ læf. "ðɛɹz lɪɾəl ɹizən waɪl aɪ wɛɹ waɪt, ɹoʊlən." ʃi ɡlænst əɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. wɑz ʃi ɡoʊɪŋ tu fæst? bʌɾ i oʊnli nɑɾəd.

"There are times to weep and times to laugh. I would like to see you laugh." She did laugh, a dry laugh. "There's little reason while I wear white, Rolan." She glanced at him out of the corner of her eye. Was she going too fast? But he only nodded.

"stɪl, aɪ wəd laɪk tə si ɪt. smaɪlz sut jəɹ feɪs. læftɝ wəd suɾ ɪɾ ivən bɛɾɝ. aɪ hæv noʊ waɪf, bʌɾ aɪ kən meɪk ə wʊmən læf, səmtaɪmz. aɪ hæv hɝd juv ə hʌzbənd?" stɑɹɾəld, feɪl tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ əɹ oʊn fiɾ ən kɑt hɝsɛlf ɑn ɪz ɑɹm. kwɪkli, ʃi snætʃt əɹ hæn əweɪ, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm pæs ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ kaʊl. hi pɔz lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə stɛɾi hɝsɛlf, ðən wɔkt ɑn wən ʃi dɪd. hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən maɪldli kjʊɹiəs. dɪspaɪt nædʒɹɪk, il kʌstəm wɑz fəɹ ə wʊmən tə də ði æskɪŋ, æftɝ ə mæn ətʃɹæktəɾ əɹ ɪntʃɹəst. ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ɡɪfs wɑz wʌn weɪ. meɪkɪŋ əɹ læf wɑz ənʌðɝ. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ ɪz nɑt laɪkɪŋ wɪmən. "aɪ də hæv ə hʌzbənd, ɹoʊlən, ən aɪ lʌv ɪm vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

"Still, I would like to see it. Smiles suit your face. Laughter would suit it even better. I have no wife, but I can make a woman laugh, sometimes. I have heard you have a husband?" Startled, Faile tripped over her own feet and caught herself on his arm. Quickly, she snatched her hand away, studying him past the edge of her cowl. He paused long enough for her to steady herself, then walked on when she did. His expression was no more than mildly curious. Despite Nadric, Aiel custom was for a woman to do the asking, after a man attracted her interest. Giving her gifts was one way. Making her laugh was another. So much for his not liking women. "I do have a husband, Rolan, and I love him very much.

vɛɹi mʌtʃ. aɪ kænt weɪt tə ɹɪtɝn tə hɪm." "wʌt hæpənz waɪl jə ɑɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn kænɑt bi hɛld əɡɛns jə wən jə pʊɾ ɔf waɪt," hi sɛd kɑmli, "bʌt pɝhæps jə wɛtləndɝz də nɑt si ɪt ðət weɪ. stɪl, ɪt kən bi loʊnli wən jə ɑɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn. pɝhæps wi kən tɔk səmtaɪmz." ðə mæn wɑntəd tə si hɝ læf, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ. hi wɑz ənaʊnsɪŋ ðəɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ɡɪv ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ətʃɹækt əɹ ɪntʃɹəst. il wɪmən ədmaɪɝd pɝsəvɪɹəns ɪn ə mæn. stɪl, ɪf kiæɾ ən beɪn wəd nɑt, kəd nɑt, hɛlp bɪɑnd ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ eɪɾ ɪn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ɹoʊlən wɑz əɹ bɛs hoʊp. ʃi θɔt ʃi kəd kənvɪns hɪm, ɡɪvən taɪm. ʌv kɔɹs ʃi kʊd; feɪn hɑɹts nɛvɝ səksiɾəd! hi wɑz ə skɔɹn aʊtkæst, æksɛptɪɾ oʊnli kəz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ niɾəd ɪz spɪɹ. bʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə ɡɪv ɪm ə ɹizən tə pɝsɪst.

Very much. I can't wait to return to him." "What happens while you are gai'shain cannot be held against you when you put off white," he said calmly, "but perhaps you wetlanders do not see it that way. Still, it can be lonely when you are gai'shain. Perhaps we can talk sometimes." The man wanted to see her laugh, and she did not know whether to laugh or cry. He was announcing that he did not intend to give up trying to attract her interest. Aiel women admired perseverance in a man. Still, if Chiad and Bain would not, could not, help beyond giving her aid in reaching the trees, Rolan was her best hope. She thought she could convince him, given time. Of course she could; faint hearts never succeeded! He was a scorned outcast, accepted only because the Shaido needed his spear. But she was going to have to give him a reason to persist.

"aɪ wəd laɪk ðæt," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli. ə lɪɾəl flɝɾɪŋ maɪt bi nɛsəsɛɹi æftɝ ɔl, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ɡoʊ fɹəm tɛlɪŋ ɪm haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi lʌvd əɹ hʌzbən stʃɹeɪt tə waɪd-aɪɾ ən bɹɛθləs. nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ ðət fɑɹ - ʃi wɑz noʊ dəmɑni! - jɛt ʃi maɪt nid tə kʌm kloʊs. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, ə lɪɾəl ɹimaɪndɝ ðət sɪvænə hæd jusɝpt ɪz "ɹaɪt" wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əmɪs. "aɪ hæv wɝk tə də naʊ, ðoʊ, ən aɪ daʊt sɪvænə wəd bi plizd ɪf aɪ spɛn ðə taɪm tɔkɪŋ tə jə ɪnstɛd." ɹoʊlən nɑɾəd əɡɛn, ən feɪl saɪd. hi maɪt noʊ haʊ tə meɪk ə wʊmən læf, əz i kleɪmd, bʌɾ i sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt tɔk vɛɹi mʌtʃ. ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə wɝk tə dʒɹɔ hɪm aʊɾ ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən dʒoʊks ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. ivən wɪð kiæɾ ən beɪnz hɛlp, il hjumɝ ɹɪmeɪn ɪŋkɑmpɹəhɛnsɪbəl tə hɝ.

"I would like that," she said carefully. A little flirting might be necessary after all, but she could not go from telling him how much she loved her husband straight to wide-eyed and breathless. Not that she had any intention of going that far - she was no Domani! - yet she might need to come close. For the time being, a little reminder that Sevanna had usurped his "right" would not go amiss. "I have work to do now, though, and I doubt Sevanna would be pleased if I spent the time talking to you instead." Rolan nodded again, and Faile sighed. He might know how to make a woman laugh, as he claimed, but he certainly did not talk very much. She was going to have to work to draw him out if she intended to get anything more than jokes she did not understand. Even with Chiad and Bain's help, Aiel humor remained incomprehensible to her.

ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə bɹɔd skwɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ət ðə nɔɹθ ɛn ə ðə sɪɾi, ə taʊɝd mæs ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɔlz ðət hæd pɹətɛktəɾ ɪts ɪnhæbəɾənts noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. feɪl θɔt ʃi hæd sin ðə leɪɾi hu hæd ɹul meɪɾən ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ fəɹ twɛnti maɪlz ɝaʊnd, ə hænsəm dɪɡnəfaɪd wɪɾoʊ ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, əmʌŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn hɔlɪŋ wɔɾɝ. waɪt-klæd mɛn ən wɪmən kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts kɹaʊɾəd ðə stoʊn-peɪv skwɛɹ. ət ði istɝn ɛn ə ðə skwɛɹ, wʌt lʊk laɪk ə sɛkʃən ə ðə sɪɾiz aʊɾɝ wɔl, ɡɹeɪ ən θɝɾi fit haɪ, wɑz æktʃəli  ðə wɔl ʌv ə hjudʒ sɪstɝn fɛd baɪ ən ækwədʌkt. fɔɹ pʌmps, itʃ wɝk baɪ ə pɛɹ ə mɛn, ɡʌʃt aʊt wɔɾɝ tə fɪl ðə bʌkəts, ə ɡʊd bɪt mɔɹ splæʃɪŋ tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ðən ðə wʊɾə əv dɛɹɾ əlaʊ ɪf ðeɪ hæd noʊn ɹoʊlən wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si. feɪl hæd kənsɪɾɝd kɹɔlɪŋ θɹu ðə tʌnəl-laɪk ækwədʌk tə ɪskeɪp, bʌt ðeɪ hæd noʊ weɪ tə kip ɛniθɪŋ dʒɹaɪ, ən wɛɹɛvɝ ɪt lɛɾ əm aʊt, ðeɪ wəd bi soʊkɪŋ wɛɾ ən mɔɹ laɪkli tə fɹiz tə dɛθ ðən meɪk ɪt mɔɹ ðən ə maɪl əɹ tu ɪn ðə snoʊ.

They had reached the broad square in front of the fortress at the north end of the city, a towered mass of gray stone walls that had protected its inhabitants no better than the city walls. Faile thought she had seen the lady who had ruled Maiden and everything for twenty miles around, a handsome dignified widow in her middle years, among the gai'shain hauling water. White-clad men and women carrying buckets crowded the stone-paved square. At the eastern end of the square, what looked like a section of the city's outer wall, gray and thirty feet high, was actually the wall of a huge cistern fed by an aqueduct. Four pumps, each worked by a pair of men, gushed out water to fill the buckets, a good bit more splashing to the paving stones than the men would have dared allow if they had known Rolan was close enough to see. Faile had considered crawling through the tunnel-like aqueduct to escape, but they had no way to keep anything dry, and wherever it let them out, they would be soaking wet and more likely to freeze to death than make it more than a mile or two in the snow.

ðəɹ wɝ tu ʌðɝ pleɪsəz ɪn ðə sɪɾi tə ɡɛt wɔɾɝ, boʊθ fɛd baɪ stoʊn kɑnduəts ʌndɝɡɹaʊnd, bʌt hɪɹ ə lɔŋ, laɪən-fʊɾɪd blækwʊd teɪbəl hæd bɪn pleɪst ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə sɪstɝn wɔl. wʌns ɪt hæd bɪn ə bæŋkəɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ðə tɑp ɪnleɪd wɪð aɪvɝi, bʌt ði aɪvɝi wɛdʒəz hæd bɪn pɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən sɛvɹəl wʊɾən wɑʃtʌbz sæɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp naʊ. ə pɛɹ ʌv wʊɾən bʌkəts stʊd bɪsaɪd ðə teɪbəl, ən ət wʌn ɛn ə kɑpɝ kɛɾəl stimd oʊvɝ ə faɪɝ meɪd fɹəm bɹoʊkən-ʌp tʃɛɹz. feɪl daʊɾɪd ðət sɪvænə hæɾ əɹ lɔnʒɹi kæɹiɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi tə seɪv əɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn ðə leɪbɝ ə hɔlɪŋ wɔɾɝ aʊt tə ðə tɛns, bʌt wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizən, feɪl wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. ə bæskəɾ ə lɔnʒɹi wɑz laɪɾɝ ðən fʊl wɔɾɝ bʌkəts. ʃi hæd kæɹiɾ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə noʊ. tu bæskəts stʊɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən bɛlt ən kɑlɝ wɑz ət wɝk, ðə slivz ə hɝ waɪt ɹoʊb ɹoʊld ʌp əz haɪ əz ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ən əɹ lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ taɪd wɪð ə stʃɹɪp ʌv waɪt klɔθ tə kip ɪt fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ɪndə ðə wɑʃtʌbz wɔɾɝ.

There were two other places in the city to get water, both fed by stone conduits underground, but here a long, lion-footed blackwood table had been placed at the foot of the cistern wall. Once it had been a banqueting table, the top inlaid with ivory, but the ivory wedges had been pried out and several wooden washtubs sat on the tabletop now. A pair of wooden buckets stood beside the table, and at one end a copper kettle steamed over a fire made from broken-up chairs. Faile doubted that Sevanna had her laundry carried into the city to save her gai'shain the labor of hauling water out to the tents, but whatever the reason, Faile was grateful. A basket of laundry was lighter than full water buckets. She had carried enough of them to know. Two baskets stood on the table, but only one woman wearing the golden belt and collar was at work, the sleeves of her white robe rolled up as high as they would go and her long dark hair tied with a strip of white cloth to keep it from falling into the washtub's water.

wən æliændɝ sɔ feɪl əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ wɪð ɹoʊlən, ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd, dʒɹaɪɪŋ əɹ bɛɹ ɑɹmz ɑn əɹ ɹoʊb. æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ʌv ɡæɹənz wɔl ən ə dʌzən mɔɹ taɪɾəlz, hæd bɪn ən ɛləɡənt, ɹɪzɝvd wʊmən, pɔɪzd ən steɪtli. æliændɝ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz stɪl pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ ə pɝpɛtʃuəli hɛɹiɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. wɪð dæmp pætʃəz ɑn əɹ ɹoʊbz ən əɹ hænz ɹɪŋkəl fɹəm lɔŋ ɪmɝʒən ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, ʃi cʊɾə pæs fəɹ ə pɹɪɾi wɑʃɝwʊmən. wɑtʃɪŋ ɹoʊlən sɛt daʊn ðə bæskəɾ ən smaɪl ət feɪl bɪfɔɹ stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ feɪl ɹɪtɝn ðə smaɪl, ʃi ɹeɪzd ə kwɪtsɪkəl aɪbɹaʊ. "hiz ðə wʌn u kæptʃɝd mi," feɪl sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ pisəz ə kloʊðɪŋ fɹəm ðə bæskəɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ivən hɪɹ əmʌŋ nʌn bʌt ɡeɪʃeɪn, ɪt wɑz bɛs tə tɔk waɪl wɝkɪŋ. "hiz wʌn ə ðə bɹʌðɝləs, ən aɪ θɪŋk i dʌzn ɹɪli əpɹuv ə meɪkɪŋ wɛtləndɝz ɡeɪʃeɪn. aɪ θɪŋk i meɪ hɛlp ʌs."

When Alliandre saw Faile approaching with Rolan, she straightened, drying her bare arms on her robe. Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan, Blessed of the Light, Defender of Garen's Wall and a dozen more titles, had been an elegant, reserved woman, poised and stately. Alliandre the gai'shain was still pretty, but she wore a perpetually harried expression. With damp patches on her robes and her hands wrinkled from long immersion in the water, she could have passed for a pretty washerwoman. Watching Rolan set down the basket and smile at Faile before striding away, watching Faile return the smile, she raised a quizzical eyebrow. "He's the one who captured me," Faile said, setting pieces of clothing from the basket on the table. Even here among none but gai'shain, it was best to talk while working. "He's one of the Brotherless, and I think he doesn't really approve of making wetlanders gai'shain. I think he may help us."

"aɪ si," æliændɝ sɛd. wɪð wʌn hænd ʃi bɹʌʃt dɛləkətli ət ðə bæk ə feɪlz ɹoʊb.

"I see," Alliandre said. With one hand she brushed delicately at the back of Faile's robe.

fɹaʊnɪŋ, feɪl twɪstəd tə lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə dɝɾ ən æʃ ðət kʌvɝɾ əɹ bæk fɹəm ðə ʃoʊldɝz daʊn; ðən hit flʌɾəd əɹ feɪs. "aɪ fɛl," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli. ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl æliændɝ wʌt hæd hæpənd wɪð nædʒɹɪk. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi kəd tɛl ɛniwʌn. "ɹoʊlən ɔfɝd tə kæɹi maɪ bæskət."

Frowning, Faile twisted to look over her shoulder. For a moment she stared at the dirt and ash that covered her back from the shoulders down; then heat flooded her face. "I fell," she said quickly. She could not tell Alliandre what had happened with Nadric. She did not think she could tell anyone. "Rolan offered to carry my basket."

æliændɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "ɪf i hɛlp mi ɪskeɪp, aɪ wəd mɛɹi hɪm. əɹ nɑt, əz i wɑntəd. hiz nɑt kwaɪt pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn bi peɪnfəl, ən maɪ hʌzbənd, ɪf aɪ hæd wʌn, wəd nɛvɝ əv tə noʊ. ɪf i hæɾ ɛni sɛns, hi wəd bi oʊvɝdʒɔɪd tə hæv mi bæk ən æsk noʊ kwɛstʃənz i dɪdnt wɑnə hɪɹ ænsɝz tə." hænz taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn ə sɪlk blaʊs, feɪl ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ.

Alliandre shrugged. "If he helped me escape, I would marry him. Or not, as he wanted. He's not quite pretty, but it wouldn't be painful, and my husband, if I had one, would never have to know. If he had any sense, he would be overjoyed to have me back and ask no questions he didn't want to hear answers to." Hands tightening on a silk blouse, Faile gritted her teeth.

æliændɝ wɑz əɹ lidʒ wʊmən, θɹu pɛɹɪn, ən ʃi hɛl tə ðət wɛl ɪnʌf, ət list ɪnsəfɑɹ əz oʊbeɪɪŋ kəmænz, bʌt ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp hæd bɪkʌm stʃɹeɪnd. ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɹid ðət ðeɪ mʌs tʃɹaɪ tə θɪŋk laɪk sɝvəns, tʃɹaɪ tə bi sɝvəns, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə sɝvaɪv, jɛt ðət mɛn ðəɾ itʃ hæd sin ði ʌðɝ kɝtsiɪŋ ən skɝiɪŋ tə oʊbeɪ. sɪvænəz pʌnɪʃməns wɝ dɛlt aʊt baɪ ðə nɪɹəst ɡeɪʃeɪn tə hænd wən ʃi meɪɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən, ən wʌns feɪl hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə swɪtʃ æliændɝ.

Alliandre was her liege woman, through Perrin, and she held to that well enough, at least insofar as obeying commands, but the nature of the relationship had become strained. They had agreed that they must try to think like servants, try to be servants, if they were to survive, yet that meant that each had seen the other curtsying and scurrying to obey. Sevanna's punishments were dealt out by the nearest gai'shain to hand when she made her decision, and once Faile had been ordered to switch Alliandre.

wɝs, æliændɝ hæd bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə ɹɪtɝn ðə feɪvɝ twaɪs. hoʊldɪŋ bæk oʊnli mɛn ə teɪst ə ðə seɪm fəɹ jɝsɛlf plʌs ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hævɪŋ tə ɛndʒjʊɹ ə dʌbəl doʊs fɹəm sʌmwʌn u wəd nɑt spɛɹ əɹ ɑɹm. ɪt hæd tə meɪk ə dɪfɝəns wən jə hæd twaɪs meɪd jəɹ lidʒ-leɪɾi kɪk ən ʃɹik.

Worse, Alliandre had been ordered to return the favor twice. Holding back only meant a taste of the same for yourself plus the other woman having to endure a double dose from someone who would not spare her arm. It had to make a difference when you had twice made your liege-lady kick and shriek.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə blaʊs ʃi wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz ðət hæd pɪkt ʌp ɛkstʃɹə dɝt wən ðə bæskət fɛl. lusənɪŋ əɹ ɡɹɪp, ʃi ɪɡzæmən ðə ɡɑɹmən æŋkʃəsli. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim ðət ʃi hæd ɡɹaʊn ðə dɝɾ ɪn. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɛlt ɹɪlif, ən ðən ɪɹɪteɪʃən ət biɪŋ ɹɪlivd. ivən mɔɹ ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ, ðə ɹɪlif dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ.

Abruptly she realized that the blouse she was gripping was one of those that had picked up extra dirt when the basket fell. Loosening her grip, she examined the garment anxiously. It did not seem that she had ground the dirt in. For a moment, she felt relief, and then irritation at being relieved. Even more irritating, the relief did not go away.

"ɹɛlə ən lətʃəl ɪskeɪp θɹi deɪz əɡoʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. "ðeɪ ʃəd bi wɛl əweɪ baɪ naʊ. wɛɹ ɪz meɪaɪɡdɪn?" ə wɝid fɹaʊn əpɪɹɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz feɪs. "ʃi ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik ɪndə θɛɝɑvəz tɛnt. θɛɝɑvə pæst əs wɪð ə ɡɹup ʌv waɪz wʌnz, ən fɹəm wʌt wi oʊvɝhɝd, ðeɪ sim tə bi ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə mit wɪð sɪvænə. meɪaɪɡdɪn ʃʌvd əɹ bæskəɾ ət mi ən sɛd ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə tʃɹaɪ. aɪ θɪŋk. . . . aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz bɪkʌmɪŋ dɛspɹɪɾ ɪnʌf tə teɪk tu mɛni tʃænsəz," ʃi sɛd wɪð ə tʌtʃ ə hoʊpləsnəs ɪn əɹ oʊn vɔɪs. "ʃi ʃʊɾə bɪn hɪɹ baɪ naʊ." feɪl dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt sloʊli. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl bɪkʌmɪŋ dɛspɹɪt. ðeɪ hæd ɡæðɝd səplaɪz fəɹ ðɛɹ ɪskeɪp-naɪvz ən fud, buts ən mɛnz bɹitʃɪz ən koʊts ðət fɪt nɪɹ ɪnʌf, ɔl kɛɹfəli hɪɾən ɪn ðə wæɡənz; ðə waɪt ɹoʊbz wəd sɝv əz blæŋkəts, ən əz kloʊks tə haɪɾ əm ɪn ðə snoʊ - bʌt ðə tʃæns tə juz ɔl ðət pɹɛpɝeɪʃən sim noʊ kloʊsɝ naʊ ðən ðə deɪ ðeɪ wɝ kæptʃɝd. oʊnli tu wiks. twɛnti-tu deɪz tə bi ɪɡzækt. ðət ʃəɾ əv nɑt bɪn lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ðɛɹ pɹitɛns ə biɪŋ sɝvəns wɑz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ əm ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɔl ðeɪ kəd du. oʊnli tu wiks, ən ðeɪ faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz dʒʌmpɪŋ tə oʊbeɪ kəmænz wɪθaʊt θɔt, wɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ pʌnɪʃməns ən wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ plizɪŋ sɪvænə. ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ kəd si ðɛmsɛlvz duɪŋ ðiz θɪŋz, nu səm pɑɹɾ ə ðɛm wɑz biɪŋ moʊldəɾ əɡɛns ðɛɹ wɪlz. fəɹ naʊ, ðeɪ kəd tɛl ðɛmsɛlvz ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs duɪŋ wʌt wɑz niɾəd tə əvɔɪd səspɪʃən əntɪl ðeɪ kəɾ ɪskeɪp, jɛɾ ɛvɹi deɪ ðə ɹiækʃənz bɪkeɪm mɔɹ ɔɾəmætɪk. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪskeɪp wɑz ə peɪl dʒɹim dʒɹimd ɪn ðə naɪɾ æftɝ ə deɪ ʌv biɪŋ ə pɝfəkt ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪn θɔɾ əz wɛl əz did? noʊ wʌn hæd dɛɹɾ æsk ðət kwɛstʃən əlaʊd, soʊ fɑɹ, ən feɪl nu ðət ʃi hɝsɛlf tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ɪt, bʌt ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz ɔlweɪz ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ kɑnʃəsnəs. ɪn ə weɪ, ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt livɪŋ. wən ɪt dɪd, wəɾ ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv bɪn ænsɝd?

"Arrela and Lacile escaped three days ago," she said in a low voice. "They should be well away by now. Where is Maighdin?" A worried frown appeared on the other woman's face. "She is trying to sneak into Therava's tent. Therava passed us with a group of Wise Ones, and from what we overheard, they seemed to be on their way to meet with Sevanna. Maighdin shoved her basket at me and said she was going to try. I think. . . . I think she's becoming desperate enough to take too many chances," she said with a touch of hopelessness in her own voice. "She should have been here by now." Faile drew a deep breath and let it out slowly. They were all becoming desperate. They had gathered supplies for their escape-knives and food, boots and men's breeches and coats that fit near enough, all carefully hidden in the wagons; the white robes would serve as blankets, and as cloaks to hide them in the snow - but the chance to use all that preparation seemed no closer now than the day they were captured. Only two weeks. Twenty-two days to be exact. That should have not been long enough to change anything, but their pretense of being servants was changing them in spite of all they could do. Only two weeks, and they found themselves jumping to obey commands without thought, worrying over punishments and whether they were pleasing Sevanna. The worst of it was, they could see themselves doing these things, knew some part of them was being molded against their wills. For now, they could tell themselves they were just doing what was needed to avoid suspicion until they could escape, yet every day the reactions became more automatic. How long before escape was a pale dream dreamed in the night after a day of being a perfect gai'shain in thought as well as deed? No one had dared ask that question aloud, so far, and Faile knew that she herself tried not to think it, but the question was always on the edge of her consciousness. In a way, she was afraid of it leaving. When it did, would it already have been answered?

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf bæk fɹəm dɪspɑndənsi. ðət wɑz ðə sɛkən tʃɹæp, ən oʊnli wɪlpaʊɝ hɛld ɪɾ oʊpən. "meɪaɪɡdɪn noʊz ʃiz tə bi kɛɹfəl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə fɝm vɔɪs. "ʃi wɪl bi hɪɹ sun, æliændɝ."

With an effort, she forced herself back from despondency. That was the second trap, and only willpower held it open. "Maighdin knows she has to be careful," she said in a firm voice. "She will be here soon, Alliandre."

"æn ɪf ʃiz kɑt?"

"And if she is caught?"

"ʃi woʊn bi!" feɪl sɛd ʃɑɹpli. ɪf ʃi wɑz. . . . noʊ. ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk ə vɪktɝi, nɑt dɪfit.

"She won't be!" Faile said sharply. If she was. . . . No. She had to think of victory, not defeat.

feɪn hɑɹts nɛvɝ wʌn. wɑʃɪŋ ðə sɪlk wɑz taɪm-kənsumɪŋ. ðə bʌkəts ʌv wɔɾɝ ðeɪ fɛtʃt fɹəm ðə sɪstɝn pʌmps wɝ aɪsi koʊld, bʌt hɑt wɔɾɝ skup fɹəm ðə kɑpɝ kɛɾəl bɹɔt ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ ɪn ðə wɑʃtʌbz ʌp tə lukwɔɹm. jə kəd nɑt wɑʃ sɪlk ɪn hɑt wɔɾɝ. sɪŋkɪŋ jəɹ hænz ɪndə ðə wɑʃtʌbz fɛlt wʌndɝfəl ɪn ðə koʊld, bʌt jə ɔlweɪz hæd tə teɪk əm aʊɾ əɡɛn, ən ðən ðə koʊld wɑz twaɪs əz bɪɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ soʊp, nɑt ðət wɑz maɪld ɪnʌf ɛniweɪ, soʊ itʃ skɝɾ ən blaʊs hæd tə bi səbmɝst wʌn baɪ wʌn ən dɛləkətli skɹʌbd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf. ðən ɪt wɑz leɪɾ ɑn ə pis ə taʊəlɪŋ ən dʒɛnli ɹoʊld ʌp tə skwiz aʊɾ əz mʌtʃ wɔɾɝ əz pɑsəbəl. ðə dæmp ɡɑɹmənt wɑz dɪpt əɡɛn, ɪn ənʌðɝ wɑʃtʌb ðət wɑz fɪld wɪð ə mɪkstʃɝ ə vɪnəɡɝ ən wɔɾɝ - ðət ɹədus feɪɾɪŋ ən ɛnhæns ðə ɡlɔs ə ðə sɪlk - ðən ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn taʊəlɪŋ əɡɛn. ðə wɛt taʊəlɪŋ wɑz ɹʌŋ aʊt hɑɹɾ ən spɹɛɾ ɪn ðə sʌn tə dʒɹaɪ wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɹum, waɪl itʃ pis ə sɪlk wɑz hʌŋ ɑn ə hɔɹəzɑntəl poʊl, slʌŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾ ʌv ə ɹʌf kænvəs pəvɪljən ɪɹɛktəɾ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə skwɛɹ, ən smuð baɪ hæn tə ɹʌb aʊt ɹɪŋkəlz. wɪð lʌk, nʌθɪŋ wəd niɾ aɪɝnɪŋ. boʊθ ə ðɛm nu haʊ sɪlk hæd tə bi kɛɹd fɔɹ, bʌɾ aɪɝnɪŋ ɪt niɾəd ɪkspɪɹiəns niðɝ ə ðɛm hæd. nʌn ə sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn dɪd, nɑɾ ivən meɪaɪɡdɪn, ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn ə leɪɾiz meɪɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ɛntɝɪŋ feɪlz sɝvəs, bʌt sɪvænə dɪd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɪkskjuzɪz. ɛvɹi taɪm feɪl əɹ æliændɝ wɛn tə hæŋ ənʌðɝ ɡɑɹmənt, ðeɪ tʃɛk ðoʊz ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɹ ən smuðd ɛni ðət sim tə niɾ ɪt.

Faint hearts never won. Washing the silk was time-consuming. The buckets of water they fetched from the cistern pumps were icy cold, but hot water scooped from the copper kettle brought the temperature in the washtubs up to lukewarm. You could not wash silk in hot water. Sinking your hands into the washtubs felt wonderful in the cold, but you always had to take them out again, and then the cold was twice as bitter. There was no soap, not that was mild enough anyway, so each skirt and blouse had to be submersed one by one and delicately scrubbed against itself. Then it was laid on a piece of toweling and gently rolled up to squeeze out as much water as possible. The damp garment was dipped again, in another washtub that was filled with a mixture of vinegar and water - that reduced fading and enhanced the gloss of the silk - then rolled up in toweling again. The wet toweling was wrung out hard and spread in the sun to dry wherever there was room, while each piece of silk was hung on a horizontal pole, slung in the shade of a rough canvas pavilion erected at the edge of the square, and smoothed by hand to rub out wrinkles. With luck, nothing would need ironing. Both of them knew how silk had to be cared for, but ironing it needed experience neither of them had. None of Sevanna's gai'shain did, not even Maighdin, though she had been a lady's maid even before entering Faile's service, but Sevanna did not accept excuses. Every time Faile or Alliandre went to hang another garment, they checked those already there and smoothed any that seemed to need it.

feɪl wɑz æɾɪŋ hɑt wɔɾɝ tə ə wɑʃtʌb wən æliændɝ sɛd bɪɾɝli, "hɪɹ kʌmz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Faile was adding hot water to a washtub when Alliandre said bitterly, "Here comes the Aes Sedai."

ɡəlinə wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, kəmplit wɪð ði eɪdʒləs feɪs ən ə ɡoʊldən ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ waɪt ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz, tu - ɪn sɪlk əz θɪk əz ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz wʊl, noʊ lɛs! - əlɔŋ wɪð ə waɪd, ɪlæbɹət bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊld ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps ðət sɪntʃt əɹ weɪs taɪtli ən ə tɔl mætʃɪŋ kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, dʒuəlz fɪt fəɹ ə mɑnɑɹk. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən səmtaɪmz ɹoʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə kæmp əloʊn, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz ɹɪtɝnd, ən ʃi dʒʌmpt wən ɛni waɪz wʌn kɹʊkəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ, ɪspɛʃli θɛɝɑvə, huz tɛnt ʃi ɔfən ʃɛɹd. ɪn ə weɪ, ðət læst wɑz ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst θɪŋ ʌv ɔl. ɡəlinə nu hu feɪl wɑz, nu hu hɝ hʌzbənd wɑz ən pɛɹɪnz kənɛkʃən tə ɹænd ælθɹ, ən ʃi θɹɛɾənd tə ɹɪvil ɪt tə sɪvænə ənlɛs feɪl ən əɹ fɹɛnz stoʊl sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə vɛɹi tɛnt ʃi slɛpt ɪn. ðət wɑz ðə θɝd tʃɹæp laɪɪŋ ɪn weɪt fəɹ ðɛm. sɪvænə wɑz əbsɛst wɪð ælθɹ, ənseɪnli kənvɪns ðət ʃi kəd sʌmhaʊ mɛɹi hɪm, ən ɪf ʃi lɝn əbaʊt pɛɹɪn, feɪl wəd nɛvɝ bi əlaʊd fɑɹ ɪnʌf aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪskeɪp. ʃi wəd bi steɪkt aʊt laɪk ə ɡoʊt tə dʒɹɔ ə laɪən.

Galina was Aes Sedai, complete with the ageless face and a golden Great Serpent ring on her finger, but she wore white gai'shain robes, too - in silk as thick as anyone else's wool, no less! - along with a wide, elaborate belt of gold and firedrops that cinched her waist tightly and a tall matching collar around her neck, jewels fit for a monarch. She was Aes Sedai, and sometimes rode out from the camp alone, but she always returned, and she jumped when any Wise One crooked a finger, especially Therava, whose tent she often shared. In a way, that last was the strangest thing of all. Galina knew who Faile was, knew who her husband was and Perrin's connection to Rand al'Thor, and she threatened to reveal it to Sevanna unless Faile and her friends stole something from the very tent she slept in. That was the third trap lying in wait for them. Sevanna was obsessed with al'Thor, insanely convinced that she could somehow marry him, and if she learned about Perrin, Faile would never be allowed far enough out of her sight to think of escape. She would be staked out like a goat to draw a lion.

feɪl hæd sin ɡəlinə slɪŋkɪŋ ən kaʊɝɪŋ, bʌt naʊ ðə sɪstɝ ɡlaɪɾɪd θɹu ðə skwɛɹ laɪk ə kwin dɪsdeɪnɪŋ ðə ɹæbəl ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðə hɪlt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ waɪz wʌnz hɪɹ fəɹ əɹ sɪmpɝ æt. ɡəlinə wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌt noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ bjuɾəfəl, ən feɪl dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌt θɛɝɑvə sɔ ɪn hɝ, ənlɛs ɪt wɑz sɪmpli ðə plɛʒɝ ə dɑməneɪɾɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət stɪl lɛf ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv waɪ ðə wʊmən ɹɪmeɪnd wən θɛɝɑvə sim tə teɪk ɛvɹi ɑpɝtunəɾi tə hjumɪlieɪt hɝ.

Faile had seen Galina slinking and cowering, but now the sister glided through the square like a queen disdaining the rabble around her, an Aes Sedai to the hilt. There were no Wise Ones here for her simper at. Galina was pretty, but nowhere near beautiful, and Faile did not understand what Therava saw in her, unless it was simply the pleasure of dominating an Aes Sedai. That still left the question of why the woman remained when Therava seemed to take every opportunity to humiliate her.

stɑpɪŋ ə peɪs fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, ɡəlinə sɝveɪɾ əm wɪð ə smɔl smaɪl ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn kɔl pɪɾiɪŋ. "ju ɑɹ nɑt pɹəɡɹɛsɪŋ vɛɹi fɑɹ ɪn jəɹ wɝk," ʃi sɛd. ʃi wɑz nɑt spikɪŋ ə ðə lɔnʒɹi.

Stopping a pace from the table, Galina surveyed them with a small smile that might have been called pitying. "You are not progressing very far in your work," she said. She was not speaking of the laundry.

ɪt wɑz feɪlz pleɪs tə də ðə tɔkɪŋ, bʌɾ æliændɝ spoʊk ʌp, ivən mɔɹ bɪɾɝli ðən bɪfɔɹ.

It was Faile's place to do the talking, but Alliandre spoke up, even more bitterly than before.

"meɪaɪɡdɪn wɛn tə fɛtʃ jəɹ aɪvɝi ɹɑd ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ɡəlinə. wən wɪl wi si səm ə ðə hɛlp jə pɹɑməst?" hɛlp ɪn ðɛɹ ɪskeɪp wɑz ðə kæɹət ɡəlinə ɔfɝɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə stɪk ə θɹɛɾənɪŋ feɪlz ɪkspoʊʒɝ. soʊ fɑɹ, haʊɛvɝ, ðeɪ hæd sin oʊnli ðə stɪk.

"Maighdin went to fetch your ivory rod this morning, Galina. When will we see some of the help you promised?" Help in their escape was the carrot Galina offered along with the stick of threatening Faile's exposure. So far, however, they had seen only the stick.

"ʃi wɛn tə θɛɝɑvəz tɛn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ?" ɡəlinə wɪspɝd, ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪnɪŋ fɹəm əɹ feɪs.

"She went to Therava's tent this morning?" Galina whispered, the blood draining from her face.

ɪt dɔn ɑn feɪl ðət ðə sʌn wɑz hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə hɝaɪzən ɪn ðə wɛst, ən əɹ hɑɹt bɪɡæn tə θʌd peɪnfəli. meɪaɪɡdɪn ʃʊɾə dʒɔɪn əm lɔŋ sɪns.

It dawned on Faile that the sun was halfway down to the horizon in the west, and her heart began to thud painfully. Maighdin should have joined them long since.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ simd ivən mɔɹ ʃeɪkən ðən ʃi. "ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ?" ɡəlinə ɹɪpiɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ə kɹaɪ wən meɪaɪɡdɪn sʌɾənli əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə θɹɔŋ ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə skwɛɹ.

The Aes Sedai seemed even more shaken than she. "This morning?" Galina repeated, looking over her shoulder. She gave a start and a cry when Maighdin suddenly appeared out of the throng of gai'shain crowding the square.

ənlaɪk æliændɝ, ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən hæd ɡɹoʊn tʌfɝ baɪ ðə deɪ sɪns ðɛɹ kæptʃɝ.

Unlike Alliandre, the golden-haired woman had grown tougher by the day since their capture.

ʃi wɑz noʊ lɛs dɛspɹɪt, bʌt ʃi sim tə foʊkəs ɪɾ ɔl ɪndə dɪtɝməneɪʃən. ʃi ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə pɹɛzəns ðət bɪlɔŋ mɔɹ tə ə kwin ðən ə leɪɾiz meɪd, ðoʊ moʊs leɪɾiz meɪdz hæɾ ɪt, bʌt naʊ ʃi stʌmbəl pæs ðɛm, dʌleɪd, ən plʌnʒd əɹ hænz ɪndə ə wɔɾɝ bʌkət, kʌpɪŋ ə dʌbəl hændfʊl tə hɝ maʊθ tə dʒɹɪŋk θɝstəli, ðən skɹʌbɪŋ ðə bæk ʌv ə hæn əkɹɔs əɹ maʊθ.

She was no less desperate, but she seemed to focus it all into determination. She always had a presence that belonged more to a queen than a lady's maid, though most lady's maids had it, but now she stumbled past them, dulleyed, and plunged her hands into a water bucket, cupping a double handful to her mouth to drink thirstily, then scrubbing the back of a hand across her mouth.

"aɪ wɑnə kɪl θɛɝɑvə wən wi ɡoʊ," ʃi sɛd θɪkli. "aɪ wəd laɪk tə kɪl əɹ naʊ." hɝ blu aɪz tʊk ɑn laɪf əɡɛn, ən hit. "jɔɹ seɪf, ɡəlinə. ʃi θɔɾ aɪ wɑz ðəɹ tə stil. aɪ hædn stɑɹɾəd lʊkɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ. . . . sʌmθɪŋ hæpənd, ən ʃi lɛft. æftɝ taɪɪŋ mi ʌp. fəɹ leɪɾɝ." ðə hit feɪɾəd fɹəm əɹ ɡeɪz tə bi ɹipleɪs baɪ pʌzəlmənt. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, ɡəlinə? ivən aɪ fil ɪt, ən aɪ hæv soʊ lɪɾəl əbɪləɾi ðiz il wɪmən dɪsaɪɾɪd aɪ wɑz noʊ deɪnʒɝ."

"I want to kill Therava when we go," she said thickly. "I would like to kill her now." Her blue eyes took on life again, and heat. "You're safe, Galina. She thought I was there to steal. I hadn't started looking. Something. . . . Something happened, and she left. After tying me up. For later." The heat faded from her gaze to be replaced by puzzlement. "What is it, Galina? Even I feel it, and I have so little ability these Aiel women decided I was no danger."

meɪaɪɡdɪn kəd tʃænəl. nɑt ɹɪlaɪəbli, ðoʊ ən nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ - fɹəm wʌt lɪɾəl feɪl nu, ðə waɪt taʊɝ wʊɾə sɛn əɹ əweɪ ɪn ə mæɾɝ ʌv wiks, ən ʃi kleɪm nɛvɝ tə hæv ɡɔn -  soʊ hɝ əbɪləɾi wəd nɑt bi ʌv mʌtʃ jus ɪn eɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪskeɪp. feɪl wʊɾə æskt wʌt ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ ɡɑt ðə tʃæns.

Maighdin could channel. Not reliably, though and not very much - from what little Faile knew, the White Tower would have sent her away in a matter of weeks, and she claimed never to have gone -  so her ability would not be of much use in aiding their escape. Faile would have asked what she was talking about, but she never got the chance.

ɡəlinəz feɪs wɑz stɪl peɪl, bʌɾ ʌðɝwaɪz ʃi wɑz ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm. ɪksɛp ðət ʃi sizd ə hændfʊl ə meɪaɪɡdɪnz kaʊl ən ðə hɛɹ bɪniθ ən ɹɛntʃt əɹ hɛd bæk. "nɛvɝ jə maɪnd wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd kuli. "nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ju. ɔl jə nid wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ mi wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt. bʌt jə ʃəd wɝi əbaʊt ðət vɛɹi hɑɹd."

Galina's face was still pale, but otherwise she was all Aes Sedai calm. Except that she seized a handful of Maighdin's cowl and the hair beneath and wrenched her head back. "Never you mind what it is," she said coolly. "Nothing to do with you. All you need worry about is getting me what I want. But you should worry about that very hard."

bɪfɔɹ feɪl kəd muv tə dɪfɛn meɪaɪɡdɪn, ənʌðɝ wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə waɪd ɡoʊldən bɛlt oʊvɝ əɹ waɪt ɹoʊbz wɑz ðɛɹ, pʊlɪŋ ɡəlinə əweɪ ən slɪŋɪŋ əɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. plʌmp ən pleɪn, ɝɑvin hæd bɪn wɪɹi-aɪɾ ən ɹɪzaɪn ðə fɝs taɪm feɪl sɔ hɝ, ðə deɪ ði ɑmɑdɪʃən wʊmən hændəɾ əɹ ðə ɡoʊldən bɛlt ʃi wɔɹ ən toʊld əɹ ʃi wɑz naʊ ɪn ðə sɝvəs ʌv "ðə leɪɾi sɪvænə." ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ deɪz hæd stɪfən ɝɑvin ivən mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ hæd meɪaɪɡdɪn, ðoʊ.

Before Faile could move to defend Maighdin, another woman wearing the wide golden belt over her white robes was there, pulling Galina away and slinging her to the ground. Plump and plain, Aravine had been weary-eyed and resigned the first time Faile saw her, the day the Amadician woman handed her the golden belt she wore and told her she was now in the service of "the Lady Sevanna." The intervening days had stiffened Aravine even more than they had Maighdin, though.

"ɑɹ jə mæd, tə leɪ hænz ɑn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ɡəlinə snæpt, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə hɝ fit. bɹʌʃɪŋ ət ðə dɝt steɪnɪŋ əɹ sɪlk ɹoʊbz, ʃi dɝɛktəɾ ɔl əɹ fjʊɹi ət ðə plʌmp wʊmən. "aɪ wɪl əv jə - "

"Are you mad, to lay hands on an Aes Sedai?" Galina snapped, struggling to her feet. Brushing at the dirt staining her silk robes, she directed all her fury at the plump woman. "I will have you - "

"ʃæl aɪ tɛl θɛɝɑvə jə wɝ mænhænlɪŋ wʌn ə sɪvænəz ɡeɪʃeɪn?" ɝɑvin bɹoʊk ɪn koʊldli. hɝ æksɛns wɝ kʌltʃɝd. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə mɝtʃən ə səm noʊt, əɹ pɝhæps ivən ə noʊbəl, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ spoʊk ʌv wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ pʊɾɪŋ ɑn waɪt. "ðə læs taɪm θɛɝɑvə θɔt jud poʊk jəɹ noʊz wɛɹ ʃi dɪdnt wɑn ɪt, ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪnsaɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz kəd hɪɹ jə skwilɪŋ ən bɛɡɪŋ."

"Shall I tell Therava you were manhandling one of Sevanna's gai'shain?" Aravine broke in coldly. Her accents were cultured. She might have been a merchant of some note, or perhaps even a noble, but she never spoke of what she had been before putting on white. "The last time Therava thought you'd poked your nose where she didn't want it, everybody inside a hundred paces could hear you squealing and begging."

ɡəlinə æktʃəli  kwɪvɝd wɪð ɹeɪdʒ, ðə fɝs taɪm feɪl hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ soʊ aʊtdʌn.

Galina actually quivered with rage, the first time Faile had ever seen an Aes Sedai so outdone.

wɪð ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt, ʃi ɡeɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝsɛlf. dʒʌst. hɝ vɔɪs dʒɹɪpt æsəd. "ɛɛs sədaɪ də wʌt wi də fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɹizənz, ɝɑvin, ɹizənz jə kəd nɑt pɑsəbli ʌndɝstænd. jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪnkɝɪŋ ðɪs dɛt wən aɪ dɪsaɪd tə kəlɛk peɪmənt. jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt tə jəɹ hɑɹt." ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊbz ə læs bɹʌʃ, ʃi stɔkt əweɪ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə kwin dɪsdeɪnɪŋ ɹæbəl bʌɾ ə lɛpɝd dɛɹɪŋ ʃip tə blɑk əɹ pæθ.

With a visible effort, she gained control of herself. Just. Her voice dripped acid. "Aes Sedai do what we do for our own reasons, Aravine, reasons you could not possibly understand. You will regret incurring this debt when I decide to collect payment. You will regret it to your heart." Giving her robes a last brush, she stalked away, no longer the queen disdaining rabble but a leopard daring sheep to block her path.

wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊ, ɝɑvin simd ʌnɪmpɹɛst, ən ʌnɪnklaɪn tə tʃæt. "sɪvænə wɑns ju, feɪl" wɑz ɔl ʃi sɛd.

Watching her go, Aravine seemed unimpressed, and uninclined to chat. "Sevanna wants you, Faile" was all she said.

feɪl dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə æsk waɪ. ʃi dʒʌs dʒɹaɪɾ əɹ hænz, ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ slivz, ən fɑloʊd ði ɑmɑdɪʃən wʊmən, æftɝ pɹɑməsɪŋ æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn tə ɹɪtɝn əz sun əz ʃi kʊd. sɪvænə wɑz fæsəneɪɾəd wɪð ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. meɪaɪɡdɪn, ði oʊnli tʃɹu leɪɾiz meɪɾ əmʌŋ əɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn, sim tə ɪntʃɹəst əɹ əz mʌtʃ əz kwin æliændɝ, ən feɪl hɝsɛlf, ə wʊmən paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf tə hæv ə kwin əz əɹ lidʒ wʊmən, ən səmtaɪmz ʃi sʌmənd wʌn ə ðɛm baɪ neɪm tə hɛlp əɹ tʃeɪnʒ kloʊðz əɹ beɪð ɪn ðə lɑɹdʒ kɑpɝ bæθtəb ðət ʃi juz mɔɹ ɔfən ðən ðə swɛt tɛnt, əɹ dʒʌs tə pɔɹ əɹ waɪn.

Faile did not bother to ask why. She just dried her hands, rolled down her sleeves, and followed the Amadician woman, after promising Alliandre and Maighdin to return as soon as she could. Sevanna was fascinated with the three of them. Maighdin, the only true lady's maid among her gai'shain, seemed to interest her as much as Queen Alliandre, and Faile herself, a woman powerful enough to have a queen as her liege woman, and sometimes she summoned one of them by name to help her change clothes or bathe in the large copper bathtub that she used more often than the sweat tent, or just to pour her wine.

ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taɪm ðeɪ wɝ ɡɪvən ðə seɪm tʃɔɹz əz əɹ ʌðɝ sɝvəns, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ æskt wɛðɝ ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn əsaɪnd wɝk əɹ lɛɾ əm ɔf kəz ʌv ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ sɪvænə wɑntəd, feɪl nu ʃi stɪl wəd bi hɛld əkaʊntəbəl fəɹ ðə lɔnʒɹi əlɔŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu. sɪvænə wɑntəd wʌt ʃi wɑntəd wən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪt, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɪkskjusɪz.

The rest of the time they were given the same chores as her other servants, but she never asked whether they had already been assigned work or let them off because of it. Whatever Sevanna wanted, Faile knew she still would be held accountable for the laundry along with the other two. Sevanna wanted what she wanted when she wanted it, and she did not accept excuses.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid fəɹ feɪl tə bi ʃoʊn ðə weɪ tə sɪvænəz tɛnt, bʌɾ ɝɑvin lɛd ðə weɪ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ ʌv wɔɾɝ kæɹiɝz əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɝs loʊ il tɛns, ən ðən ʃi pɔɪntəɾ ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən tə sɪvænəz tɛn ən sɛd, "ðɪs weɪ, fɝst." feɪl stɑpt wɛɹ ʃi stʊd.

There was no need for Faile to be shown the way to Sevanna's tent, but Aravine led the way through the throng of water carriers until they reached the first low Aiel tents, and then she pointed in the opposite direction to Sevanna's tent and said, "This way, first." Faile stopped where she stood.

"waɪ?" ʃi æsk səspɪʃəsli. ðəɹ wɝ æktʃəli  mɛn ən wɪmən əmʌŋ sɪvænəz sɝvəns u wɝ dʒɛləs ə ði ətɛnʃənz ʃi ɡeɪv feɪl, æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən ðoʊ feɪl hæd nɛvɝ dɪtɛktəd ðəɾ ɪn ɝɑvin, səm ə ðə ɹɛs maɪt wɛl tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ əm ɪn tʃɹʌbəl baɪ pæsɪŋ ɑn fɔls ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz.

"Why?" she asked suspiciously. There were actually men and women among Sevanna's servants who were jealous of the attentions she gave Faile, Alliandre and Maighdin, and though Faile had never detected that in Aravine, some of the rest might well try to get them in trouble by passing on false instructions.

"ju wɪl wɑnə si ðɪs bɪfɔɹ jə si sɪvænə. bɪliv mi." feɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə dɪmæn mɔɹ ɛkspləneɪʃən, bʌɾ ɝɑvin sɪmpli tɝn ən wɔkt əweɪ. feɪl ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðə skɝts ə hɝ ɹoʊbz ən fɑloʊd.

"You will want to see this before you see Sevanna. Believe me." Faile opened her mouth to demand more explanation, but Aravine simply turned and walked away. Faile gathered up the skirts of her robes and followed.

ɔl sɔɹts ən saɪzəz ə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz stʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə tɛns, ðɛɹ wilz ɹipleɪs baɪ slɛdz.

All sorts and sizes of carts and wagons stood among the tents, their wheels replaced by sleds.

moʊst wɝ paɪl haɪ wɪð bʌndəlz ən wʊɾən kɹeɪts ən bæɹəlz, wɪð ðə wilz taɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðə loʊdz, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə fɑloʊ ɝɑvin fɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɔ ə flætbɛd kɑɹt ðət hæd bɪn ɛmptid.

Most were piled high with bundles and wooden crates and barrels, with the wheels tied on top of the loads, but she did not have to follow Aravine far before she saw a flatbed cart that had been emptied.

ɪksɛp ðət ðə kɑɹt bɛd wɑz nɑɾ ɛmpti. tu wɪmən leɪ ɑn ðə ɹʌf wʊɾən plæŋks, neɪkəɾ ən kɹuli hɑɡtid, ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə koʊl jɛt pæntɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ. boʊθ wɪmənz hɛdz hʌŋ taɪɹədli, bʌɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ sʌmhaʊ nu feɪl wɑz ðɛɹ, boʊθ lʊkt ʌp. ɹɛlə, ə dɑɹk tɛɹən əz tɔl əz moʊst il wɪmən, əvɝɾəd əɹ aɪz ɪn ɪmbɛɹəsmənt.

Except that the cart bed was not empty. Two women lay on the rough wooden planks, naked and cruelly hogtied, shivering in the cold yet panting as if they were running. Both women's heads hung tiredly, but as if they somehow knew Faile was there, both looked up. Arrela, a dark Tairen as tall as most Aiel women, averted her eyes in embarrassment.

lətʃəl, slɪm ən peɪl ən kɛɹhinɪn, wɛn bɹaɪt ɹɛd. "ðeɪ wɝ bɹɔt bæk ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ," ɝɑvin sɛd, wɑtʃɪŋ feɪlz feɪs. "ðeɪ wɪl bi əntaɪd bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk, sɪns ɪts ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪv tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp, ðoʊ aɪ daʊt ðəl bi ɪn ɛni kəndɪʃən tə wɔk bɪfɔɹ təmɑɹoʊ."

Lacile, slim and pale and Cairhienin, went bright red. "They were brought back this morning," Aravine said, watching Faile's face. "They will be untied before dark, since it's the first time they've tried to escape, though I doubt they will be in any condition to walk before tomorrow."

"waɪ dɪd jə ʃoʊ mi ðɪs?" feɪl sɛd. ðeɪ hæd bɪn soʊ kɛɹfəl tə kip ðə kənɛkʃən bɪtwin əm ə sikɹət. "ju fɝɡɛt, maɪ leɪɾi, aɪ wɑz ðəɹ wən jə wɝ ɔl pʊɾ ɪn waɪt." ɝɑvin stʌɾid əɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən sʌɾənli tʊk feɪlz hænz ən tɝn əm soʊ ðəɾ əɹ oʊn hænz wɝ bɪtwin feɪlz pɑmz. bɛndɪŋ əɹ niz dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə nilɪŋ, ʃi sɛd kwɪkli, "ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə ɹibɝθ, aɪ, ɝɑvin kɑɹnəl, də plɛdʒ maɪ fiəlti ən oʊbiɾiəns ɪn ɔl θɪŋz tə ðə leɪɾi feɪl teɪbɑɹə."

"Why did you show me this?" Faile said. They had been so careful to keep the connection between them a secret. "You forget, my Lady, I was there when you were all put in white." Aravine studied her a moment, then suddenly took Faile's hands and turned them so that her own hands were between Faile's palms. Bending her knees just short of kneeling, she said quickly, "Under the Light and by my hope of rebirth, I, Aravine Carnel, do pledge my fealty and obedience in all things to the Lady Faile t'Aybara."

oʊnli lətʃəl əpɪɹd tə hæv noʊɾəst; ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɔkɪŋ pæs peɪd noʊ maɪn tə tu ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪmən. feɪl dʒɝkt əɹ hænz fɹi. "haʊ dʒju noʊ ðət neɪm?" ʃi hæd hæd tə ɡɪv mɔɹ ə hɝ neɪm ðən feɪl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən feɪl bæʃɪɹ wʌns ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət nʌn ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæɾ ə klu hu dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ wɑz. əsaɪd fɹəm æliændɝ ən ði ʌðɝz, oʊnli ɡəlinə nu ðə tʃɹuθ.

Only Lacile appeared to have noticed; the Shaido walking past paid no mind to two gai'shain women. Faile jerked her hands free. "How do you know that name?" She had had to give more of her name than Faile, of course, but she had chosen Faile Bashere once she realized that none of the Shaido had a clue who Davram Bashere was. Aside from Alliandre and the others, only Galina knew the truth.

əɹ soʊ ʃi hæd θɔt. "æn u hæv jə toʊld?" "aɪ lɪsən, maɪ leɪɾi. aɪ oʊvɝhɝd ɡəlinə spikɪŋ tə ju, wʌns." æŋzaɪəɾi tʌtʃt ɝɑvinz vɔɪs. "æn aɪ hæv toʊl noʊ wʌn." ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn sɝpɹaɪz ðət feɪl wɑntəd tə haɪɾ əɹ neɪm, ðoʊ klɪɹli teɪbɑɹə mɛnt nʌθɪŋ tə hɝ. pɝhæps ɝɑvin kɑɹnəl wɑz nɑɾ əɹ tʃɹu neɪm, əɹ nɑɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt. "ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, sikɹəts mʌs bi hɛld əz kloʊsli əz ɪn æmədɔɹ. aɪ nu ðiz wɪmən wɝ jʊɹz, bʌɾ aɪ toʊl noʊ wʌn. aɪ noʊ jə ɪntɛn tə ɪskeɪp. aɪv bɪn sɝɾən sɪns ðə sɛkən əɹ θɝd deɪ, ən nʌθɪŋ aɪv sin sɪns kənvɪnsɪz mi ʌðɝwaɪz. æksɛp maɪ oʊθ, ən teɪk mi wɪð ju. aɪ kən hɛlp, ən wʌɾ ɪz mɔɹ, aɪ kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd. aɪ hæv pɹuvd ɪt baɪ kipɪŋ jəɹ sikɹəts. pliz." ðə læst wɝd keɪm aʊt stʃɹeɪnd, əz ɪf fɹəm sʌmwʌn ənjuz tə seɪɪŋ ɪt. ə noʊbəlwʊmən, ðɛn, ɹæðɝ ðən ə mɝtʃənt.

Or so she had thought. "And who have you told?" "I listen, my Lady. I overheard Galina speaking to you, once." Anxiety touched Aravine's voice. "And I have told no one." She did not sound surprised that Faile wanted to hide her name, though clearly t'Aybara meant nothing to her. Perhaps Aravine Carnel was not her true name, or not all of it. "In this place, secrets must be held as closely as in Amador. I knew these women were yours, but I told no one. I know you intend to escape. I've been certain since the second or third day, and nothing I've seen since convinces me otherwise. Accept my oath, and take me with you. I can help, and what is more, I can be trusted. I have proved it by keeping your secrets. Please." The last word came out strained, as if from someone unused to saying it. A noblewoman, then, rather than a merchant.

ðə wʊmən hæd pɹuvən nʌθɪŋ bɪɑn ðət ʃi kəd spaɪ aʊt sikɹəts, bʌt ðəɾ ɪn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ə jusfəl tʃɹeɪt. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, feɪl nu ʌv ət lis tu ɡeɪʃeɪn u hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp ən bɪn bɪtʃɹeɪd baɪ ʌðɝz. səm pipəl ɹɪli dɪd tʃɹaɪ tə fɛðɝ ðɛɹ oʊn nɛsts noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. bʌɾ ɝɑvin ɔlɹɛɾi nu ɪnʌf tə ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ. feɪl θɔɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ hɪɾən naɪf əɡɛn. ə dɛd wʊmən kəd bɪtʃɹeɪ nʌθɪŋ. bʌt ðə naɪf wɑz hæf ə maɪl əweɪ, ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə noʊ weɪ tə haɪd ðə bɑɾi, ən bɪsaɪdz, ðə wʊmən cʊɾə kɝid feɪvɝ wɪð sɪvænə dʒʌs baɪ seɪɪŋ ʃi θɔt feɪl wɑz plænɪŋ ɪskeɪp. teɪkɪŋ ɝɑvinz hænz bɪtwin hɝz, ʃi spoʊk əz kwɪkli əz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪ də æksɛp jəɹ plɛdʒ ən wɪl dɪfɛn ən pɹətɛk jə ən jʊɹz θɹu bæɾəlz ɹæk ən wɪntɝz blæst ən ɔl ðət taɪm meɪ bɹɪŋ. naʊ. dʒju noʊ ɛniwʌn ɛls u kən bi tʃɹʌstɪd? nɑt pipəl jə θɪŋk jə kən tʃɹʌst, pipəl jə noʊ jə kæn."

The woman had proven nothing beyond that she could spy out secrets, but that in itself was a useful trait. On the other hand, Faile knew of at least two gai'shain who had tried to escape and been betrayed by others. Some people really did try to feather their own nests no matter what the circumstances. But Aravine already knew enough to ruin everything. Faile thought about her hidden knife again. A dead woman could betray nothing. But the knife was half a mile away, she could think of no way to hide the body, and besides, the woman could have curried favor with Sevanna just by saying she thought Faile was planning escape. Taking Aravine's hands between hers, she spoke as quickly as the other woman had. "Under the Light, I do accept your pledge and will defend and protect you and yours through battle's wrack and winter's blast and all that time may bring. Now. Do you know anyone else who can be trusted? Not people you think you can trust, people you know you can."

"nɑt wɪð ðɪs, maɪ leɪɾi," ɝɑvin sɛd ɡɹɪmli. hɝ feɪs ʃoʊn wɪð ɹɪlif, ðoʊ. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ feɪl wəɾ æksɛp hɝ. ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɹɪlif ɹæðɝ ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls meɪd feɪl tɛn tə bɪliv ɪn hɝ. tɛn tə, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt tə seɪ kəmplitli. "hæf wəd bɪtʃɹeɪ ðɛɹ oʊn mʌðɝz ɪn hoʊps ə baɪɪŋ fɹiɾəm, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf ɑɹ tu əfɹeɪd tə tʃɹaɪ əɹ tu stʌn tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd nɑt tə pænɪk. ðəɹ mʌs bi sʌm, ən aɪ hæv maɪ aɪ ɑn wʌn əɹ tu, bʌɾ aɪ wɑnə bi vɛɹi kɛɹfəl. wʌn mɪsteɪk ɪz wʌn mɔɹ ðən əl bi əlaʊd."

"Not with this, my Lady," Aravine said grimly. Her face shone with relief, though. She had not been sure Faile would accept her. That it was relief rather that anything else made Faile tend to believe in her. Tend to, which was not to say completely. "Half would betray their own mothers in hopes of buying freedom, and the other half are too afraid to try or too stunned to be trusted not to panic. There must be some, and I have my eye on one or two, but I want to be very careful. One mistake is one more than I'll be allowed."

"vɛɹi kɛɹfəl," feɪl əɡɹid. "dɪd sɪvænə ɹɪli sɛn fəɹ mi?

"Very careful," Faile agreed. "Did Sevanna really send for me?

"ɪf ʃi dɪdnt - "

"If she didn't - "

ɪt sim ðət ʃi hæd, ən feɪl wɑz kwɪk əbaʊt ɹitʃɪŋ sɪvænəz tɛnt - kwɪkɝ ðən ʃi wəɾ əv laɪkt, ɪn tʃɹuθ; ɪt wɑz ɪɹəteɪɾɪŋ tə lip tə əvɔɪd sɪvænəz dɪsplɛʒɝ - bʌt noʊ wʌn peɪɾ əɹ ðə slaɪɾəst hid wən ʃi wɔkt ɪn ən stʊd mikli baɪ ði ɛntʃɹi flæps.

It seemed that she had, and Faile was quick about reaching Sevanna's tent - quicker than she would have liked, in truth; it was irritating to leap to avoid Sevanna's displeasure - but no one paid her the slightest heed when she walked in and stood meekly by the entry flaps.
