"ju wɑnə əbændən hɪm? tə ðæt!" noʊ wʌn kəd hændəl soʊ mʌtʃ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, nɑt ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst sɝkəl, nɑɾ əneɪɾɪd. səpoʊzədli ə sɑŋɡɹil ɪɡzɪstəd, ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɛvɝ meɪd, ən ɪf wʌt ʃi hæd hɝd wɑz kɝɛkt, ðət maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hændəl ðɪs. meɪbi. bʌt fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd hɝd, noʊ wʊmən kəd juz ɪɾ ən lɪv, nɑt wɪθaʊt tɛɹæŋɡɹil meɪd fəɹ ðə pɝpəs, ən noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin wʌn ðət ʃi nu ʌv. ʃʊɹli noʊ sɪstɝ wəd tʃɹaɪ ivən ɪf ʃi hæd faʊnd wʌn. ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ kəd lɛvəl maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz əɾ ə stʃɹoʊk! noʊ sɪstɝ wəd tʃɹaɪ ɪksɛpt pɝhæps wʌn ə ðə blæk ədʒɑ. əɹ wɝs, wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Aviendha gave herself a shake and stopped staring westward. The glow remained around her, and Elayne could feel that she had drawn on the Source as deeply as she could. But even as Aviendha turned to her, she felt the amount of saidar the other woman held dwindle. "We must not, Elayne." Aghast, Elayne twisted in Fireheart's saddle to stare at her. "You want to abandon him? To that!" No one could handle so much of saidar, not the strongest circle, not unaided. Supposedly a sa'angreal existed, greater than anything else ever made, and if what she had heard was correct, that might be able to handle this. Maybe. But from what she had heard, no woman could use it and live, not without ter'angreal made for the purpose, and no one had ever seen one that she knew of. Surely no sister would try even if she had found one. That much of the One Power could level mountain ranges at a stroke! No sister would try except perhaps one of the Black Ajah. Or worse, one of the Forsaken.

meɪbi mɔɹ ðən wʌn. wʌɾ ɛls kəɾ ɪt bi? ən eɪvinhə sɪmpli wɑntəd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt, wən ʃi mʌs noʊ ðət ɹænd wɑz ðɛɹ?

Maybe more than one. What else could it be? And Aviendha simply wanted to ignore it, when she must know that Rand was there?

ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, ʌnəwɛɹ, wɝ stɪl weɪɾɪŋ peɪʃənli ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, kipɪŋ wɑtʃ ɑn ðə tʃɹilaɪn ɝaʊn ðə mɛdoʊ ən lɪɾəl kənsɝnd wɪð ðəɾ æftɝ ðɛɹ ɹɪsɛpʃən ət ðə mænɝ, ðoʊ keɪsil wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə, ə slaɪt fɹaʊn vɪzəbəl bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɝ hɛlmət.

The Guardswomen, unaware, were still waiting patiently on their horses, keeping watch on the treeline around the meadow and little concerned with that after their reception at the manor, though Caseille was watching Elayne and Aviendha, a slight frown visible behind the face-bars of her helmet.

ʃi nu ðeɪ nɛvɝ dɪleɪɾ əɾ oʊpənɪŋ ə ɡeɪtweɪ. ðə mɛn fɹəm ðə mænɝ wɝ ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ pækhɔɹs, pɔɪŋ ət ðə bʌndəlz ən əpɛɹənli ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt sʌmθɪŋ hæd bɪn ɪnkluɾəd. eɪvinhə stɪl muvd əɹ ɡɹeɪ kloʊsɝ tə ɪleɪnz blæk ən spoʊk ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət wəd nɑt kæɹi.

She knew they never delayed at opening a gateway. The men from the manor were gathered around their packhorse, pawing at the bundles and apparently arguing over whether or not something had been included. Aviendha still moved her gray closer to Elayne's black and spoke in a voice that would not carry.

"wi noʊ nʌθɪŋ, ɪleɪn. nɑt wɛðɝ hiz dænsɪŋ ðə spɪɹz əɹ ðɪs ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ɪf i dænsəz ðə spɪɹz ən wi ɹʌʃ ɪn, wɪl i ətæk əs bɪfɔɹ i noʊz u ɑɹ? wɪl wi dɪstʃɹækt ɪm kəz i dʌz nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ʌs, ən əlaʊ hɪz ɛnəmiz tə wɪn? ɪf i daɪz, wɪl faɪn u tʊk ɪz laɪf ən kɪl ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪf wi ɡoʊ tə hɪm naʊ, wi ɡoʊ blaɪnli, ən wi meɪ bɹɪŋ dɪzæstɝ ɑn əɹ bæks." "wi kəd bi kɛɹfəl," ɪleɪn sɛd sʌlənli. ɪɾ ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd əɹ ðət ʃi wɑz filɪŋ sʌlən, ən ʃoʊɪŋ ɪt, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz ɹaɪɾ əɹ mudz ən tʃɹaɪ nɑt lɛɾ əm ɡɛt ði ʌpɝ hæn kəmplitli. "wi doʊn əv tə tʃɹævəl ɹaɪt tə ðə spɑt." ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ paʊtʃ, filɪŋ ðə smɔl aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə siɾəd wʊmən ðət nɛsəld ɪnsaɪd, ʃi lʊk pɔɪntɪdli əɾ əɹ sɪstɝz æmbɝ bɹutʃ. "laɪt, eɪvinhə, wɪv æŋɡɹil, ən niðɝ ʌv əs ɪz ɪɡzækli hɛlpləs." oʊ, laɪt, naʊ ʃi wɑz saʊndɪŋ pɛtʃələnt. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət boʊθ ə ðɛm təɡɛðɝ, æŋɡɹil ən ɔl, wəd bi flaɪz bæɾəlɪŋ ə fleɪm əɡɛnst wʌt ðeɪ kəd sɛns, bʌɾ ivən soʊ, ə flaɪbaɪɾ ət ðə ɹaɪt moʊmən maɪt meɪk ðə dɪfɝəns. "æn doʊn tɛl mi əl ɛndeɪnʒɝ ðə beɪbi. mɪn sɛd ʃɪl bi bɔɹn stʃɹɔŋ ən hɛlθi. jə toʊl mi soʊ jɝsɛlf. ðət minz əl lɪv ət lis lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ maɪ dɔɾɝ tə bi bɔɹn." ʃi hoʊp fəɹ ə dɔɾɝ. faɪɹhɑɹt tʃoʊz ðət moʊmən tə nɪp ət ðə ɡɹeɪ, ən sɪswaɪ nɪp bæk, ən fəɹ ə bɪɾ ɪleɪn wɑz ɑkjəpaɪd wɪð ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl ən kipɪŋ eɪvinhə fɹəm biɪŋ θɹoʊn ən tɛlɪŋ keɪsil ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt niɾ ɛni hɛlp, ən baɪ ði ɛn ʌv ɪt, ʃi wɑz nɑt filɪŋ sʌlən ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi wɑntəd tə smæk faɪɹhɑɹt ɹaɪt bɪtwin ɪz ɪɹz.

"We know nothing, Elayne. Not whether he is dancing the spears or this is something else. If he dances the spears and we rush in, will he attack us before he knows who are? Will we distract him because he does not expect us, and allow his enemies to win? If he dies, we will find who took his life and kill them, but if we go to him now, we go blindly, and we may bring disaster on our backs." "We could be careful," Elayne said sullenly. It infuriated her that she was feeling sullen, and showing it, but all she could do was ride her moods and try not let them get the upper hand completely. "We don't have to Travel right to the spot." Gripping her pouch, feeling the small ivory carving of a seated woman that nestled inside, she looked pointedly at her sister's amber brooch. "Light, Aviendha, we have angreal, and neither of us is exactly helpless." Oh, Light, now she was sounding petulant. She knew very well that both of them together, angreal and all, would be flies battling a flame against what they could sense, but even so, a flybite at the right moment might make the difference. "And don't tell me I'll endanger the baby. Min said she will be born strong and healthy. You told me so yourself. That means I will live at least long enough for my daughter to be born." She hoped for a daughter. Fireheart chose that moment to nip at the gray, and Siswai nipped back, and for a bit Elayne was occupied with getting her gelding under control and keeping Aviendha from being thrown and telling Caseille that they did not need any help, and by the end of it, she was not feeling sullen any longer. She wanted to smack Fireheart right between his ears.

əsaɪd fɹəm meɪkɪŋ ði ænəməl oʊbeɪ ðə ɹeɪnz, eɪvinhə bɪheɪvd əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæd hæpən əɾ ɔl. ʃi dɪd fɹaʊn, ə lɪɾəl ənsɝteɪnli, hɝ feɪs fɹeɪm baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʊl ə hɝ ʃɔl, bʌɾ əɹ ənsɝɾənti hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə hɔɹs.

Aside from making the animal obey the reins, Aviendha behaved as if nothing had happened at all. She did frown, a little uncertainly, her face framed by the dark wool of her shawl, but her uncertainty had nothing to do with the horse.

"aɪ hæv toʊl jə əbaʊt ðə ɹɪŋz ɪn ɹɪɾiən," ʃi sɛd sloʊli, ən ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ən ɪmpeɪʃənt nɑd. ɛvɹi wʊmən u wɑntəd tə bɪkʌm ə waɪz wʌn wɑz sɛn θɹu ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪɡæn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil juz tə tɛs nɑvəsɪz fəɹ biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪn ðɪs wʌn, ə wʊmən sɔ hɝ hoʊl laɪf. ɔl ə hɝ pɑsəbəl laɪvz, ɹɪli, ɛvɹi dɪsɪʒən meɪd dɪfɹənli, ən ɪnfənət fæn ə laɪvz beɪst ɑn dɪfɝɪŋ tʃɔɪsəz. "noʊ wʌn kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɔl ə ðæt, ɪleɪn, oʊnli bɪts ən pisəz. aɪ nu aɪ wəd lʌv ɹænd ælθɹ . . . " ʃi wɑz stɪl ənkʌmftəɹbəl səmtaɪmz əbaʊt juzɪŋ dʒʌst ɪz fɝs neɪm ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌðɝz, "æn ðəɾ aɪ wəd faɪn sɪstɝ-waɪvz. fəɹ moʊs θɪŋz, ɔl jə ɹɪteɪn ɪz ə veɪɡ ɪmpɹɛʃən ət bɛst. ə hɪn ʌv wɔɹnɪŋ, səmtaɪmz. aɪ θɪŋk ɪf wi ɡoʊ tə hɪm naʊ, sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi bæd wɪl hæpən. meɪbi wʌn ʌv əs wɪl daɪ, meɪbi boʊθ ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv wʌt mɪn sɛd." ðət ʃi sɛd mɪnz neɪm wɪθaʊt fʌmbəlɪŋ wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə hɝ kənsɝn. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ mɪn vɛɹi wɛl, ən juʒəwəli neɪmd əɹ fɔɹməli, əz mɪn fɑɹʃɔ. "pɝhæps hɪl daɪ. pɝhæps sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. aɪ də nɑt noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ - meɪbi wɪl ɔl sɝvaɪv, ən wɪl sɪɾ ɝaʊn ə faɪɝ wɪð ɪm ɹoʊstɪŋ pɛkɑɹə wən wi faɪn ɪm - bʌt ðə ɡlɪmɝ ʌv ə wɔɹnɪŋ ɪz ðəɹ ɪn maɪ hɛd." ɪleɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli. ðən ʃi kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn, æŋɡɝ dʒɹeɪnɪŋ əweɪ laɪk wɔɾɝ daʊn ə hoʊl, ən əɹ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt. pɝhæps eɪvinhəz ɡlɪmɝ wɑz tʃɹu ən pɝhæps nɑt, bʌt ðə fækt wɑz ðəɾ əɹ ɑɹɡjəməns hæd bɪn ɡʊd fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪsk teɪkən ɪn ɪɡnɝəns, ən teɪkɪŋ ɪt maɪt bɹɪŋ dɪzæstɝ. ðə bikən hæd ɡɹoʊn bɹaɪɾɝ stɪl. ən i wɑz ðɛɹ, ɹaɪt wɛɹ ðə bikən wɑz. ðə bɑn dɪd nɑt tɛl əɹ soʊ, nɑɾ ət ðɪs dɪstəns, bʌt ʃi nu. ən ʃi nu ʃi hæd tə liv ɪm tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪmsɛlf waɪl ʃi tʊk kɛɹ ʌv ændɝ.

"I have told you about the rings in Rhuidean," she said slowly, and Elayne gave an impatient nod. Every woman who wanted to become a Wise One was sent through a ter'angreal before she began training. It was something like the ter'angreal used to test novices for being raised to Accepted in the White Tower, except that in this one, a woman saw her whole life. All of her possible lives, really, every decision made differently, an infinite fan of lives based on differing choices. "No one can remember all of that, Elayne, only bits and pieces. I knew I would love Rand al'Thor . . . " she was still uncomfortable sometimes about using just his first name in front of others, "and that I would find sister-wives. For most things, all you retain is a vague impression at best. A hint of warning, sometimes. I think if we go to him now, something very bad will happen. Maybe one of us will die, maybe both in spite of what Min said." That she said Min's name without fumbling was a measure of her concern. She did not know Min very well, and usually named her formally, as Min Farshaw. "Perhaps he will die. Perhaps something else. I do not know for sure - maybe we will all survive, and we will sit around a fire with him roasting pecara when we find him - but the glimmer of a warning is there in my head." Elayne opened her mouth angrily. Then she closed it again, anger draining away like water down a hole, and her shoulders slumped. Perhaps Aviendha's glimmer was true and perhaps not, but the fact was that her arguments had been good from the start. A great risk taken in ignorance, and taking it might bring disaster. The beacon had grown brighter still. And he was there, right where the beacon was. The bond did not tell her so, not at this distance, but she knew. And she knew she had to leave him to take care of himself while she took care of Andor.

"aɪ doʊn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə titʃ jə əbaʊt biɪŋ ə waɪz wʌn, eɪvinhə," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ju ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi mʌtʃ waɪzɝ ðən aɪ. nɑt tə mɛnʃən bɹeɪvɝ ən mɔɹ kulhɛɾɪd. wi ɹɪtɝn tə keɪɛmlɪn." eɪvinhə kʌlɝd feɪnli ʌndɝ ðə pɹeɪz - ʃi kəd bi vɛɹi sɛnsəɾɪv, ət taɪmz - bʌt ʃi weɪstəd noʊ taɪm ɪn oʊpənɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ə ɹoʊteɪɾɪŋ vju ʌv ə steɪbliɑɹɾ ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ðət waɪɾənd ɪndə ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ ən lɛt snoʊ fɹəm ðə mɛdoʊ fɔl ɑntu ðə klin-swɛpt peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz nɪɹ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əweɪ əz meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. ðə sɛns ə bɝdʒɪt, sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə pæləs, spɹæŋ əlaɪv ɪn ɪleɪnz hɛd. bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ə hɛdeɪk ən ə saʊɝ stʌmək, nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl əkɝənsɪz ə leɪt, bʌt ðeɪ suɾəd ɪleɪnz muɾ ɔl tu wɛl.

"I don't have anything to teach you about being a Wise One, Aviendha," she said quietly. "You are already much wiser than I. Not to mention braver and more coolheaded. We return to Caemlyn." Aviendha colored faintly under the praise - she could be very sensitive, at times - but she wasted no time in opening the gateway, a rotating view of a stableyard in the Royal Palace that widened into a hole in the air and let snow from the meadow fall onto the clean-swept paving stones as near three hundred miles away as made no difference. The sense of Birgitte, somewhere in the palace, sprang alive in Elayne's head. Birgitte had a headache and a sour stomach, not unusual occurrences of late, but they suited Elayne's mood all too well.

aɪ mʌs liv ɪm tə teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪmsɛlf, ʃi θɔɾ əz ʃi ɹoʊd θɹu. laɪt, haʊ ɔfən hæd ʃi θɔt ðæt? noʊ mæɾɝ. ɹænd wɑz ðə lʌv ə hɝ hɑɹɾ ən ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv əɹ laɪf, bʌɾ ændɝ wɑz əɹ duɾi.

I must leave him to take care of himself, she thought as she rode through. Light, how often had she thought that? No matter. Rand was the love of her heart and the joy of her life, but Andor was her duty.

tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən

CHAPTER 11

tɔk ə dɛts ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz pəzɪʃən soʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn sim tə bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə hoʊl ɪn ðə wɔl əɡɛns ðə stʃɹit, ɪndə ə skwɛɹ mɑɹkt aʊt fəɹ seɪfti baɪ sænd-fɪld waɪn bæɹəlz stændɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz.

Talk of Debts The gateway was positioned so that Elayne seemed to be riding out of a hole in the wall against the street, into a square marked out for safety by sand-filled wine barrels standing on the paving stones.

ɑdli, ʃi kəd nɑt fil ə sɪŋɡəl wʊmən tʃænəlɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə pæləs, ðoʊ ɪt haʊz mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti wɪð ði əbɪləɾi. səm wəd bi steɪʃən ɑn ðə sɪɾiz aʊɾɝ wɔlz, ʌv kɔɹs, tu fɑɹ fəɹ əɹ tə sɛns ɛniθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə lɪŋk sɝkəl, ən ə fju wəd bi aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ɔltəɡɛðɝ, jɛt sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz juzɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ, wɛðɝ tə tʃɹaɪ fɔɹsɪŋ wʌn ə ðə kæptɪv sʌldəm tə ədmɪt ðət ʃi ɹɪli kəd si wivz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ əɹ sɪmpli tə smuð ðə ɹɪŋkəlz fɹəm ə ʃɔl wɪθaʊt hiɾɪŋ ən aɪɝn. nɑt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðoʊ. wɪndfɪndɝ ɛɹəɡəns ɔfən mætʃt ðə wɝst ʃoʊn baɪ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, jɛɾ ivən ðət mʌs bi kwɔʃt baɪ wʌt ðeɪ sɛnst. ɪleɪn θɔt ðəɾ ɪf ʃi klaɪm tə ə haɪ wɪndoʊ, ʃi mʌs bi eɪbəl tə si ðə wivz ə ðət ɡɹeɪt bikən, hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz dɪstən əz ðeɪ wɝ. ʃi fɛlt laɪk ən æn ðət hæd dʒʌs bɪkʌm əwɛɹ ə maʊntənz, ən æn kəmpɛɹɪŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝl tə ðə hɪlz ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz hɛld ɪn ɑ. jɛs, ivən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz mʌs bi wɔkɪŋ smɔl ɪn ðə feɪs ə ðæt.

Oddly, she could not feel a single woman channeling anywhere in the palace, though it housed more than a hundred and fifty with the ability. Some would be stationed on the city's outer walls, of course, too far for her to sense anything short of a linked circle, and a few would be out of the city altogether, yet someone in the palace was almost always using saidar, whether to try forcing one of the captive sul'dam to admit that she really could see weaves of the One Power or simply to smooth the wrinkles from a shawl without heating an iron. Not this morning, though. Windfinder arrogance often matched the worst shown by any Aes Sedai, yet even that must be quashed by what they sensed. Elayne thought that if she climbed to a high window, she must be able to see the weaves of that great beacon, hundreds of leagues distant as they were. She felt like an ant that had just become aware of mountains, an ant comparing the Spine of the World to the hills it had always held in awe. Yes, even the Windfinders must be walking small in the face of that.

ɑn ði istɝn saɪɾ ə ðə pæləs ən fɹʌntɪɾ ɑn nɔɹθ ən saʊθ baɪ tu-stɔɹi-haɪ steɪbəlz ə pjʊɹ waɪt stoʊn, ðə kwinz steɪbliɑɹd tʃɹədɪʃənəli wɑz ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə ðə kwinz pɝsənəl hɔɹsəz ən kæɹɪdʒɪz, ən ʃi hæd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊvɝ juzɪŋ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑz æknɑlɪdʒ hɝz. ðə stɛps ðət lɛd tə ðə θɹoʊn wɝ əz dɛləkəɾ əz ɛni kɔɹt dæns, ən ɪf ðə dæns səmtaɪmz keɪm tə ɹɪzɛmbəl ə tævɝn bɹɔl, jə stɪl hæd tə meɪk jəɹ stɛps wɪð ɡɹeɪs ən pɹisɪʒən ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɡeɪn jəɹ ɡoʊl. kleɪmɪŋ ðə pɝkwəzɪts bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ kənfɝm hæd kɑst səm wɪmən ðɛɹ tʃæns tə ɹul. ɪn ði ɛnd, ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə tʃɹænzɡɹɛʃən ðət wəd meɪk əɹ sim oʊvɝ-pɹaʊd. bɪsaɪdz, ðə kwinz steɪbliɑɹd wɑz ɹɛləɾɪvli smɔl ən hæd noʊ ʌðɝ juz. ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ pipəl tə kip əweɪ fɹəm ən oʊpənɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪ hɪɹ. ɪn fækt, wən ʃi ɛntɝɾ ɪt, ðə stoʊn-peɪv jɑɹd wɑz ɛmpti əpɑɹt fɹəm ə sɪŋɡəl ɹɛd-koʊɾəd ɡɹum stændɪŋ ɪn wʌn ə ði ɑɹtʃt steɪbəl dɔɹweɪz, bʌɾ i tɝn tə ɡɪv ə ʃaʊɾ ɪnsaɪd, ən dʌzənz mɔɹ keɪm spɪlɪŋ aʊɾ əz ʃi ɡaɪɾəd faɪɹhɑɹt klɪɹ ə ðə mɑɹkt-ɔf skwɛɹ. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi maɪɾ əv ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ən ɑntʊɹɑʒ ə paʊɝfəl lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ dʒʌs hoʊpt ʃi hæd. keɪsil bɹɔt ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən ɔɹɾɝd moʊs tə dɪsmaʊn ən si tə ðɛɹ ænəməlz. ʃi ən hæf ə dʌzən mɔɹ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, kipɪŋ wɑtʃ oʊvɝ ðə hɛdz ə ðə pipəl əfʊt. ivən hɪɹ, ʃi wəd nɑt liv ɪleɪn ənɡɑɹɾɪd. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli hɪɹ, wɛɹ ʃi feɪs mɔɹ deɪnʒɝ ðən ɪn ɛni mænɝ ʃi hæd vɪzəɾəd. ðə mæðɝɪn mɛn mɪld əbaʊt, ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ɡɹumz ən ɡɑɹdz waɪl ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə waɪt stoʊn bælkəniz ən kɑləneɪdz ðəɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðə jɑɹɾ ən ðə spaɪɹz ən ɡoʊldən doʊmz vɪzəbəl bɪɑnd. ðə koʊl sim lɛs hɪɹ ðən ɪn ðə maʊntənz -  ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛɾ ɪt tʌtʃ hɝ, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəɾ ət pɹɛzənt, dɪd nɑt meɪk əɹ toʊɾəli ʌnəwɛɹ - bʌt mɛn ən wɪmən ən hɔɹsəz ɔl stɪl bɹið feɪn plumz ə mɪst. ði oʊɾɝ ə hɔɹs dʌŋ sim stʃɹɔŋ, tu, æftɝ ðə klin ɛɹ ə ðə maʊntənz. ə hɑt bæθ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə ɹɔɹɪŋ faɪɝ wəd bi wɛlkəm. æftɝwɝd, ʃi wəɾ əv tə plʌnʒ bæk ɪndə ðə bɪznəs ə sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt ɹaɪt naʊ ə lɔŋ soʊk wəd bi dʒʌs ðə θɪŋ.

On the eastern side of the palace and fronted on north and south by two-story-high stables of pure white stone, the Queen's Stableyard traditionally was given over to the Queen's personal horses and carriages, and she had hesitated over using it before the Lion Throne was acknowledged hers. The steps that led to the throne were as delicate as any court dance, and if the dance sometimes came to resemble a tavern brawl, you still had to make your steps with grace and precision in order to gain your goal. Claiming the perquisites before being confirmed had cost some women their chance to rule. In the end, she had decided it was not a transgression that would make her seem over-proud. Besides, the Queen's Stableyard was relatively small and had no other use. There were fewer people to keep away from an opening gateway here. In fact, when she entered it, the stone-paved yard was empty apart from a single red-coated groom standing in one of the arched stable doorways, but he turned to give a shout inside, and dozens more came spilling out as she guided Fireheart clear of the marked-off square. After all, she might have returned with an entourage of powerful lords and ladies, or perhaps they just hoped she had. Caseille brought the Guardswomen through the gateway, and ordered most to dismount and see to their animals. She and half a dozen more remained in their saddles, keeping watch over the heads of the people afoot. Even here, she would not leave Elayne unguarded. Particularly here, where she faced more danger than in any manor she had visited. The Matherin men milled about, getting in the way of grooms and Guards while gaping at the white stone balconies and colonnades that overlooked the yard and the spires and golden domes visible beyond. The cold seemed less here than in the mountains -  refusing to let it touch her, as far as she could at present, did not make her totally unaware - but men and women and horses all still breathed faint plumes of mist. The odor of horse dung seemed strong, too, after the clean air of the mountains. A hot bath in front of a roaring fire would be welcome. Afterward, she would have to plunge back into the business of securing the throne, but right now a long soak would be just the thing.

ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡɹumz ɹæn tə faɪɹhɑɹt. wʌn tʊk ɪz bɹaɪɾəl wɪð ə hɝid kɝtsi fəɹ ɪleɪn, mɔɹ kənsɝnd wɪð siɪŋ ðət ðə tɔl ɡɛldɪŋ meɪd noʊ bɑðɝ waɪl ɪleɪn dɪsmaʊntɪd ðən wɪð meɪkɪŋ kɝɾəsiz hɝsɛlf, ən ənʌðɝ u meɪɾ ɪz baʊ ən ɹɪmeɪn bɛnt wɪð ɪz hænz meɪkɪŋ ə stɝəp fəɹ ɪleɪn. niðɝ ɡeɪv mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns ət ðə vju ʌv ə snoʊ-kʌvɝd maʊntən mɛdoʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd nɔɹməli si ə stoʊn wɔl. ðə steɪbəlwɝkɝz wɝ əkʌstəm tə ɡeɪtweɪz baɪ naʊ. ʃi hæd hɝd ðət ðeɪ ɡɑɹnɝd dʒɹɪŋks ɪn ðə tævɝnz baɪ boʊstɪŋ ə haʊ ɔfən ðeɪ sɔ ðə paʊɝ juzd ən ðə θɪŋz ðeɪ səpoʊzədli hæd sin dʌn wɪð ɪt. ɪleɪn kəɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt ðoʊz teɪlz saʊndəd laɪk baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɛɹəmɪlə. ʃi ɹæðɝ ɛndʒɔɪd ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə tʃuɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz.

A pair of grooms ran to Fireheart. One took his bridle with a hurried curtsy for Elayne, more concerned with seeing that the tall gelding made no bother while Elayne dismounted than with making courtesies herself, and another who made his bow and remained bent with his hands making a stirrup for Elayne. Neither gave more than a glance at the view of a snow-covered mountain meadow where they would normally see a stone wall. The stableworkers were accustomed to gateways by now. She had heard that they garnered drinks in the taverns by boasting of how often they saw the Power used and the things they supposedly had seen done with it. Elayne could imagine what those tales sounded like by the time they reached Arymilla. She rather enjoyed the thought of Arymilla chewing her fingernails.

əz ʃi sɛt fʊɾ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ə klʌstɝ ʌv ɡɑɹdzwɪmən əpɪɹɾ ɝaʊn hɝ, ɪn kɹɪmzən hæts wɪð waɪt plumz laɪɪŋ flæɾ ɑn ðə bɹɔd bɹɪmz, ən leɪs-ɛdʒ kɹɪmzən sæʃɪz, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən, ðət slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ bɹaɪt bɹɛstpleɪts. nɑɾ əntɪl ðən dɪd keɪsil teɪk ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ʌv ɪleɪnz ɛskɔɹt tə ðə steɪbəl. ðɛɹ ɹipleɪsməns wɝ dʒʌst əz wɛɹi, aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, hænz hʌvɝɪŋ nɪɹ ðɛɹ sɔɹd hɪls, ɪksɛp fəɹ dɪni, ə waɪd, plæsəd-feɪst wʊmən u kæɹiɾ ə lɔŋ bɹæstʌɾɪd kʌdʒəl. ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli naɪn ɪn nʌmbɝ -  oʊnli naɪn, ɪleɪn θɔt bɪɾɝli.

As she set foot on the paving stones, a cluster of Guardswomen appeared around her, in crimson hats with white plumes lying flat on the broad brims, and lace-edged crimson sashes, embroidered with the White Lion, that slanted across their bright breastplates. Not until then did Caseille take the remainder of Elayne's escort to the stable. Their replacements were just as wary, eyes watching every direction, hands hovering near their sword hilts, except for Deni, a wide, placid-faced woman who carried a long brassstudded cudgel. They were only nine in number -  Only nine, Elayne thought bitterly.

aɪ niɾ oʊnli naɪn bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪtsɛlf!  - jɛɾ ɛvɹi wʌn u kæɹiɾ ə sɔɹd wɑz ɛkspɝt.

I need only nine bodyguards in the Royal Palace itself!  - yet every one who carried a sword was expert.

wɪmən u fɑloʊd ðə "tʃɹeɪɾ ə ðə sɔɹd," əz keɪsil kɔld ɪt, hæd tə bi ɡʊd, əɹ ɛls sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðeɪ wɝ kʌt daʊn baɪ səm fɛloʊ huz oʊnli ædvæntɪdʒ wɑz stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪnʌf tə bæɾɝ əɹ daʊn.

Women who followed the "trade of the sword," as Caseille called it, had to be good, or else sooner or later they were cut down by some fellow whose only advantage was strength enough to batter her down.

dɪni pəzɛs noʊ fəsɪlɪɾi wɪð ə sɔɹɾ əɾ ɔl, bʌt ðə fju mɛn u hæd tɛstəɾ əɹ kʌdʒəl ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd duɪŋ soʊ. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ bʌlk, dɪni wɑz vɛɹi kwɪk, ən ʃi hæd noʊ kɑnsɛpt ə faɪɾɪŋ fɛɹ, əɹ ə pɹæktəs, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Deni possessed no facility with a sword at all, but the few men who had tested her cudgel regretted doing so. Despite her bulk, Deni was very quick, and she had no concept of fighting fair, or of practice, for that matter.

ɹæsɔɹiə, ðə stɑki ʌndɝ-lutɛnən ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, simd ɹɪlivd wən ðə ɡɹumz lɛd faɪɹhɑɹɾ ɔf. ɪf ɪleɪnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd hæd ðɛɹ weɪ, noʊ wʌn ɪksɛp ðɛmsɛlvz wʊɾə bɪn əlaʊd wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ. wɛl, meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ nɑt kwaɪt ðət bæd, bʌt ðeɪ lʊkt wɪð səspɪʃən əɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə. ɹæsɔɹiə, ə tɛɹən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ blu aɪz ən ðə jɛloʊ hɛɹ ʃi wɔɹ kʌt ʃɔɹt, wɑz əmʌŋ ðə wɝst ɪn ðət ɹəɡɑɹd, ivən ɪnsɪstɪŋ ɑn wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kʊks meɪk ɪleɪnz milz ən hævɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ teɪstəd bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz bɹɔɾ ʌp. ɪleɪn hæd nɑt pɹətɛstəd, haʊɛvɝ oʊvɝ-zɛləs ðeɪ maɪt bi. wʌn ɪkspɪɹiəns ə dʒɹʌɡd waɪn wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf, ivən wən ʃi nu ʃi wəd lɪv ət lis lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə bɛɹ əɹ tʃaɪld. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz niðɝ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmənz mɪstʃɹʌs nɔɹ ðə nid fəɹ ɪt ðət taɪɾənd əɹ maʊð. ɪt wɑz bɝdʒɪt, wivɪŋ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾəd steɪbliɑɹd, bʌt nɑt təwɔɹd hɝ.

Rasoria, the stocky under-lieutenant in charge, seemed relieved when the grooms led Fireheart off. If Elayne's bodyguard had their way, no one except themselves would have been allowed within arm's reach. Well, maybe they were not quite that bad, but they looked with suspicion at almost everyone except Birgitte and Aviendha. Rasoria, a Tairen despite her blue eyes and the yellow hair she wore cut short, was among the worst in that regard, even insisting on watching the cooks make Elayne's meals and having everything tasted before it was brought up. Elayne had not protested, however over-zealous they might be. One experience of drugged wine was more than enough, even when she knew she would live at least long enough to bear her child. But it was neither the Guardswomen's mistrust nor the need for it that tightened her mouth. It was Birgitte, weaving her way through the crowded stableyard, but not toward her.

eɪvinhə wɑz læs tə əpɪɹ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, æftɝ ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz θɹu, ən bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɪŋk aʊɾ ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns, ɪleɪn stɑɹɾəd ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf soʊ sʌɾənli ðəɾ əɹ ɛskɔɹt hæd tə lip tə meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. əz kwɪkli əz ʃi muvd, ðoʊ, bɝdʒɪt, wɪð əɹ θɪk ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd hæŋɪŋ tə hɝ weɪst, wɑz ðəɹ fɝst, hɛlpɪŋ eɪvinhə daʊn ən hændɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ oʊvɝ tə ə lɔŋ-feɪst ɡɹum u simd ɔlmoʊst əz lɛɡi əz sɪswaɪ. eɪvinhə ɔlweɪz hæd mɔɹ dɪfəkəlti ɡɛɾɪŋ ɔf ə hɔɹs ðən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn, bʌt bɝdʒɪt hæd mɔɹ ðən əsɪstəns ɪn maɪnd. ɪleɪn ən əɹ ɛskɔɹɾ ɝaɪv dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə hɪɹ ðə wʊmən seɪ tə eɪvinhə ɪn ə loʊ, hɝid vɔɪs, "dɪd ʃi dʒɹɪŋk əɹ ɡoʊts mɪlk? dɪd ʃi ɡɛɾ ɪnʌf slip? ʃi filz. . . ." hɝ vɔɪs tʃɹeɪld ɔf ət ði ɛnd, ən ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə feɪs ɪleɪn, aʊtwɝdli kɑm, ən ənsɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn əɹ ɹaɪt ðɛɹ. ðə bɑn dɪd wɝk boʊθ weɪz.

Aviendha was last to appear out of the gateway, of course, after she was sure that everyone was through, and before she let the gateway wink out of existence, Elayne started in her direction, striding off so suddenly that her escort had to leap to maintain their guarding ring around her. As quickly as she moved, though, Birgitte, with her thick golden braid hanging to her waist, was there first, helping Aviendha down and handing the gray mare over to a long-faced groom who seemed almost as leggy as Siswai. Aviendha always had more difficulty getting off a horse than getting on, but Birgitte had more than assistance in mind. Elayne and her escort arrived just in time to hear the woman say to Aviendha in a low, hurried voice, "Did she drink her goat's milk? Did she get enough sleep? She feels. . . ." Her voice trailed off at the end, and she drew a deep breath before turning to face Elayne, outwardly calm, and unsurprised to find her right there. The bond did work both ways.

bɝdʒɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə bɪɡ wʊmən, ðoʊ ʃi stʊd tɔlɝ ðən ɪleɪn ɪn əɹ hil buts, əz tɔl əz eɪvinhə, bʌt ʃi juʒəwəli hæɾ ə pɹɛzəns ðət wɑz oʊnli haɪɾənd baɪ ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz, ə ʃɔɹt ɹɛd koʊt wɪð ə haɪ waɪt kɑlɝ wɔɹn oʊvɝ bæɡi blu tʃɹaʊzɝz tʌkt ɪndə ɡlimɪŋ blæk buts, fɔɹ ɡoʊldən nɑts ɑn əɹ lɛft ʃoʊldɝ ən fɔɹ bænz ʌv ɡoʊld ɑn itʃ waɪt kʌf. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi wɑz bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ, ə hɪɹoʊ aʊɾ ə lɛdʒənd. ʃi ɹɪmeɪnd wɛɹi ʌv tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪv ʌp tə ðoʊz lɛdʒənz; ʃi kleɪm ðət ðə stɔɹiz wɝ ɡɹoʊsli ɪnfleɪɾəd wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt kəmplit fæbɹɪkeɪʃənz. jɛt ʃi wɑz stɪl ðə seɪm wʊmən u hæd dʌn ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz ðət fɔɹm ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðoʊz lɛdʒənz ən mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz. naʊ, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ əpɛɹən kəmpoʊʒɝ, əniz tɪŋ ðə kənsɝn fəɹ ɪleɪn ðət floʊd θɹu ðə bɑn əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ hɛdeɪk ən əɹ sʌlən stʌmək. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðəɾ ɪleɪn heɪɾəd fəɹ əm tə tʃɛk ɑn əɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ðət wɑz nɑt ðə hoʊl ɹizən fəɹ ɪleɪnz ɪɹɪteɪʃən, bʌt ðə bɑn lɛt bɝdʒɪt noʊ dʒʌs haʊ ʌpsɛt ʃi wɑz. eɪvinhə, kɑmli ənɹæpɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl fɹəm ɝaʊn əɹ hɛɾ ən dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ətɛmptəd ðə ɡeɪz ʌv ə wʊmən u hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ ən sɝɾənli wɑz nɑɾ ɪnvɑlvd wɪð ɛniwʌn ɛls u hæd dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. ʃi maɪɾ əv mænədʒd ɪɾ ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt waɪɾənd əɹ aɪz fəɹ ən æɾəd tʌtʃ ʌv ɪnəsəns. bɝdʒɪt wɑz ə bæɾ ɪnfluəns ɑn əɹ ɪn səm weɪz. "aɪ dʒɹæŋk ðə ɡoʊts mɪlk," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə lɛvəl vɔɪs, ɔl tu kɑnʃəs ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɹɪŋɪŋ ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. feɪsɪŋ aʊtwɝd, aɪz skænɪŋ ðə jɑɹɾ ən ðə bælkəniz ən ðə ɹuftɑps, nɪɹli ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz sɝɾənli lɪsnɪŋ. "aɪ ɡɑɾ ɪnʌf slip. ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls jə wɑnə æsk mi?" eɪvinhəz tʃiks kʌlɝd feɪnli.

Birgitte was not a big woman, though she stood taller than Elayne in her heeled boots, as tall as Aviendha, but she usually had a presence that was only heightened by the uniform of the Captain-General of the Queen's Guards, a short red coat with a high white collar worn over baggy blue trousers tucked into gleaming black boots, four golden knots on her left shoulder and four bands of gold on each white cuff. After all, she was Birgitte Silverbow, a hero out of legend. She remained wary of trying to live up to those legends; she claimed that the stories were grossly inflated where they were not complete fabrications. Yet she was still the same woman who had done every one of the things that formed the heart of those legends and more besides. Now, despite her apparent composure, unease tinged the concern for Elayne that flowed through the bond along with her headache and her sullen stomach. She knew very well that Elayne hated for them to check on her behind her back. That was not the whole reason for Elayne's irritation, but the bond let Birgitte know just how upset she was. Aviendha, calmly unwrapping her shawl from around her head and draping it over her shoulders, attempted the gaze of a woman who had done nothing wrong and certainly was not involved with anyone else who had done anything wrong. She might have managed it if she had not widened her eyes for an added touch of innocence. Birgitte was a bad influence on her in some ways. "I drank the goat's milk," Elayne said in a level voice, all too conscious of the Guardswomen ringing the three of them. Facing outward, eyes scanning the yard and the balconies and the rooftops, nearly every one was certainly listening. "I got enough sleep. Is there anything else you want to ask me?" Aviendha's cheeks colored faintly.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hæv ɔl ði ænsɝz aɪ nid fəɹ ðə moʊmənt," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ə hɪn ə ðə blʌʃ ɪleɪn hæd bɪn hoʊpɪŋ fɔɹ. ðə wʊmən nu ʃi wɑz taɪɝd, nu ʃi hæd tə bi laɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðə slip.

"I think I have all the answers I need for the moment," Birgitte replied without a hint of the blush Elayne had been hoping for. The woman knew she was tired, knew she had to be lying about the sleep.

ðə bɑnd wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ɪnkənvinjən ət taɪmz. ʃi hæd dʒɹʌŋk nʌθɪŋ bʌt hæf ə kʌp ʌv ɪkstʃɹimli wɛl wɔɾɝd waɪn læs naɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə hæv bɝdʒɪts mɔɹnɪŋ-æftɝ hɛɾ ən əɹ saʊɝ stʌmək. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi hæd spoʊkən tə əbaʊt ðə bɑn hæd mɛnʃən ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə kaɪnd, bʌt ʃi ən bɝdʒɪɾ ɔl tu ɔfən mɪɹɝd wʌn ənʌðɝ, fɪzɪkəli ən ɪmoʊʃnəli.

The bond was decidedly inconvenient at times. She had drunk nothing but half a cup of extremely well watered wine last night, but she was beginning to have Birgitte's morning-after head and her sour stomach. None of the other Aes Sedai she had spoken to about the bond had mentioned anything of the kind, but she and Birgitte all too often mirrored one another, physically and emotionally.

ðə læs pɹizɛntəd ɹil pɹɑbləmz wən əɹ mudz wɝ ɑn ə sisɔ. səmtaɪmz ʃi mænədʒ tə ʃɹʌɡ ɪɾ ɔf, əɹ faɪɾ ɪɾ ɔf, bʌt tədeɪ ʃi nu ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə sʌfɝ əntɪl bɝdʒɪt wɑz hild. ʃi θɔt ðə mɪɹɝɪŋ mʌst əkɝ kəz ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ wɪmən. noʊ wʌn hæd hɝɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn bɑndɪŋ ənʌðɝ wʊmən bɪfɔɹ. fju hæd hɝɾ ʌv ɪt naʊ, tə tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ, ən səm ə ðɛm sim tə bɪliv ɪt kəd nɑt bi tʃɹu. eɪ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz meɪl əz ʃʊɹli əz ə bʊl wɑz meɪl. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðæt, ən nɑt mɛni stɑp tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət "ɛvɹiwʌn nu" dɪzɝv kloʊs ɪɡzæməneɪʃən.

The last presented real problems when her moods were on a seesaw. Sometimes she managed to shrug it off, or fight it off, but today she knew she was going to have to suffer until Birgitte was Healed. She thought the mirroring must occur because they were both women. No one had heard of anyone bonding another woman before. Few had heard of it now, to tell the truth, and some of them seemed to believe it could not be true. A Warder was male as surely as a bull was male. Everyone knew that, and not many stopped to think that anything that "everyone knew" deserved close examination.

biɪŋ kɑɾ ɪn ə laɪ, wən ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ɛɡwinz dɪkteɪɾ əbaʊt lɪvɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz, meɪɾ ɪleɪn dɪfɛnsɪv, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ blʌnt. "ɪz daɪɛlɪn bæk?" "noʊ," bɝdʒɪt sɛd dʒʌst əz blʌnli, ən ɪleɪn saɪd. daɪɛlɪn hæd lɛf ðə sɪɾi deɪz bɪfɔɹ ɛɹəmɪləz ɑɹmi əpɪɹd, teɪkɪŋ ɹin kɔɹli wɪð əɹ tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz ən spiɾ əɹ tʃɹævəl, ən ə ɡɹeɪt dil dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn daɪɛlɪnz ɹɪtɝn. ɑn wʌt nuz ʃi bɹɔt bæk. ɑn wɛðɝ ʃi bɹɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz nuz. tʃuzɪŋ u wəd bi kwin ʌv ændɝ wɑz kwaɪt sɪmpəl, bɔɪl daʊn tə ɛsɛntʃəlz. ðəɹ wɝ oʊvɝ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd haʊsəz ɪn ðə ɹɛlm, bʌɾ oʊnli naɪntin stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ʌðɝz wəd fɑloʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ lɛd. juʒəwəli, ɔl naɪntin stʊd bɪhaɪn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, əɹ moʊst ə ðɛm, ənlɛs ʃi wɑz pleɪnli ɪnkɑmpəɾənt. haʊs mæntʃɹ hæd lɔs ðə θɹoʊn tə tʃɹəkənd wən mɔɹdʒɹɛlən daɪɾ oʊnli kəz tɪɡɹeɪn, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, hæd vænɪʃt ən mæntʃɹ hæd bɪɡʌn ɹʌnɪŋ hɛvəli tə bɔɪ tʃɪlʒɹən. ən kəz mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkən hæd ɡæðɝd θɝtin haʊsəz ɪn əɹ səpɔɹt. oʊnli tɛn ə ðə naɪntin wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi tə əsɛn ðə θɹoʊn, baɪ lɔ ən kʌstəm. ivən kleɪməns u stɪl θɔt ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv ðə θɹoʊn ðɛmsɛlvz juʒəwəli fɛl ɪn wɪð ðə ɹɛst, əɹ ət lis fɛl saɪlən ən ɡeɪv ʌp ðɛɹ pɝsut, wʌns ənʌðɝ wʊmən hæd tɛn haʊsəz əɾ əɹ bæk.

Being caught in a lie, when she was trying to follow Egwene's dictate about living as if she had already taken the Three Oaths, made Elayne defensive, and that made her blunt. "Is Dyelin back?" "No," Birgitte said just as bluntly, and Elayne sighed. Dyelin had left the city days before Arymilla's army appeared, taking Reanne Corly with her to make gateways and speed her travel, and a great deal depended on Dyelin's return. On what news she brought back. On whether she brought anything besides news. Choosing who would be Queen of Andor was quite simple, boiled down to essentials. There were over four hundred Houses in the realm, but only nineteen strong enough that others would follow where they led. Usually, all nineteen stood behind the Daughter-Heir, or most of them, unless she was plainly incompetent. House Mantear had lost the throne to Trakand when Mordrellen died only because Tigraine, the Daughter-Heir, had vanished and Mantear had begun running heavily to boy children. And because Morgase Trakand had gathered thirteen Houses in her support. Only ten of the nineteen were necessary to ascend the throne, by law and custom. Even claimants who still thought they should have the throne themselves usually fell in with the rest, or at least fell silent and gave up their pursuit, once another woman had ten Houses at her back.

θɪŋz hæd bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf wən ʃi hæd θɹi dɪklɛɹd ɹaɪvəlz, bʌt naʊ nɑiən ən ɛləniə wɝ junaɪɾəd bɪhaɪn ɛɹəmɪlə mɑɹn, ʌv ɔl pipəl, ðə lis laɪkli ʌv ðə θɹi tə hæv səksiɾəd, ən ðət mɛnt ʃi hæd tu haʊzɪz - tu lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kaʊnt;

Things had been bad enough when she had three declared rivals, but now Naean and Elenia were united behind Arymilla Marne, of all people, the least likely of the three to have succeeded, and that meant she had two Houses - two large enough to count;

mæðɝɪn ən ðoʊz eɪtin ʌðɝz ʃi hæd vɪzəɾəd wɝ tu smɔl - hɝ oʊn tʃɹəkən ən daɪɛlɪnz tæɹɑvɪn, tə feɪs sɪks. oʊ, daɪɛlɪn ɪnsɪstəd ðət kɑɝənd, koʊələn ən ɹɛnʃɝ wəd kʌm tə ɪleɪn, ən nɔɹwlɪn ən pɛnʒɹ ən tʃɹæmən bɪsaɪdz, bʌt ðə fɝs θɹi wɑntəd daɪɛlɪn hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə θɹoʊn, ən ðə læs θɹi sim tə hæv ɡɔn ɪndə haɪbɝneɪʃən. daɪɛlɪn wɑz fɝm ɪn əɹ lɔɪəlti, ðoʊ, ən taɪɝləs ɑn ɪleɪnz bɪhæf. ʃi pɝsɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ bɪlif ðət səm ə ðə haʊsəz ðət wɝ kipɪŋ saɪlən kəd bi kənvɪns tə səpɔɹɾ ɪleɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪleɪn kəd nɑɾ əpɹoʊtʃ əm hɝsɛlf, bʌt daɪɛlɪn kʊd. ən naʊ ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən vɝdʒd ɑn dɛspɹɪt. sɪks haʊsəz səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə, ən oʊnli ə ful wəd θɪŋk ʃi hæd nɑt sɛn filɝz aʊt təwɔɹd ði ʌðɝz. əɹ ðət səm maɪt lɪsən dʒʌs kəz ʃi dɪɾ əv sɪks ɔlɹɛɾi.

Matherin and those eighteen others she had visited were too small - her own Trakand and Dyelin's Taravin, to face six. Oh, Dyelin insisted that Carand, Coelan and Renshar would come to Elayne, and Norwelyn and Pendar and Traemane besides, but the first three wanted Dyelin herself on the throne, and the last three seemed to have gone into hibernation. Dyelin was firm in her loyalty, though, and tireless on Elayne's behalf. She persisted in her belief that some of the Houses that were keeping silent could be convinced to support Elayne. Of course, Elayne could not approach them herself, but Dyelin could. And now the situation verged on desperate. Six Houses supporting Arymilla, and only a fool would think she had not sent feelers out toward the others. Or that some might listen just because she did have six already.

dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət keɪsil ən əɹ ɡɑɹdz hæd veɪkeɪɾəd ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, ɪleɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hæd tə θɹɛd ðɛɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ðoʊ ə kɹaʊd. ðə mɛn fɹəm mæðɝɪn wɝ faɪnəli daʊn ɔf ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl mɔɪlɪŋ əbaʊt, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðɛɹ hælbɝdz ən pɪkɪŋ əm ʌp oʊnli tə dʒɹɑp əm əɡɛn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ənloʊd ðɛɹ pækhɔɹs ðəɹ ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd. wʌn ə ðə bɔɪz wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ ə tʃɪkən ðət sʌmhaʊ hæd ɡɑɾən lus ən wɑz skʌɾəlɪŋ bɪtwin ðə hɔɹsəz' lɛɡz, waɪl wʌn ə ðə ɹɪŋkəld oʊl mɛn ʃaʊɾəd ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, ðoʊ wɛðɝ fəɹ ðə bɔɪ əɹ ðə tʃɪkən wɑz ənklɪɹ.

Despite the fact that Caseille and her Guards had vacated the courtyard, Elayne and the others had to thread their way across the paving stones though a crowd. The men from Matherin were finally down off their horses, but they were still moiling about, dropping their halberds and picking them up only to drop them again, trying to unload their packhorse there in the stableyard. One of the boys was chasing a chicken that somehow had gotten loose and was scuttling between the horses' legs, while one of the wrinkled old men shouted encouragement, though whether for the boy or the chicken was unclear.

ə lɛðɝ-feɪs bænɝmən wɪð ðə mɛɹəs fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪt hɛɹ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ, ɪn ə feɪɾəd ɹɛd koʊt ðət stʃɹeɪn əkɹɔs ɪz bɛli, wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪstæblɪʃ ɔɹɾɝ wɪð ðə hɛlp ʌv ən oʊnli slaɪtli jʌŋɡɝ ɡɑɹdzmæn, boʊθ ə ðɛm laɪkli ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðɛɹ pɛnʃənz, əz ə ɡʊd mɛni hæd, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ ə ðə bɔɪz simd əbaʊt tə liɾ ɪz ʃæɡi hɔɹs ɪndə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf, ən bɝdʒɪt hæd tə ɔɹɾɝ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn kəɾ ɛntɝ. ðə bɔɪ, ə fʌz-tʃik læɾ u kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn əbʌv fɔɹtin, ɡeɪpt ət bɝdʒɪɾ əz waɪdli əz i hæɾ ət ðə pæləs. ʃi wɑz sɝɾənli mɔɹ pɪktʃɝəsk ɪn əɹ junəfɔɹm ðən ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɪn ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ən i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. ɹæsɔɹiə ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃʌv bæk təwɔɹd ði oʊl bænɝmən, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd.

A leather-faced bannerman with the merest fringe of white hair remaining, in a faded red coat that strained across his belly, was trying to establish order with the help of an only slightly younger Guardsman, both of them likely returned from their pensions, as a good many had, but another of the boys seemed about to lead his shaggy horse into the palace itself, and Birgitte had to order him out of the way before Elayne could enter. The boy, a fuzz-cheeked lad who could not have been above fourteen, gaped at Birgitte as widely as he had at the palace. She was certainly more picturesque in her uniform than the Daughter-Heir in a riding dress, and he had already seen the Daughter-Heir. Rasoria gave him a shove back toward the old bannerman, shaking her head.

"aɪ doʊnt neɪmɪŋ noʊ wʌɾ aɪ kən də wɪð ðɛm," bɝdʒɪt ɡɹʌmbəld əz ə meɪd lɪvɹiɾ ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt tʊk ɪleɪnz kloʊk ən ɡlʌvz ɪn ðə smɔl ɛntʃɹi hɔl. smɔl ɪn tɝmz ə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs. wɪð ɡɪldɪd stænd-læmps flɪkɝɪŋ bɪtwin nɛɹoʊ, fluɾəd waɪt kɑləmz, ɪt wɑz hæf əɡɛn ðə saɪz ə mæðɝɪnz meɪn ɛntʃɹi hɔl, ðoʊ ðə silɪŋ wɑz nɑt soʊ haɪ. ənʌðɝ meɪd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ə hɝ dʒɹɛs, ə ɡɝl nɑt ðət mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən ðə bɔɪ hu hæd tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ɪnsaɪd, ɔfɝɾ ə ɹoʊpwɝk sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ wɪð tɔl kʌps ə stimɪŋ spaɪst waɪn bɪfɔɹ saɪməlteɪniəs fɹaʊnz fɹəm eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt meɪɾ əɹ ʃaɪ bæk. "ðə fleɪmɪŋ bɔɪz fɔl əslip ɪf ðəɹ pʊɾ ɑn ɡɑɹd," bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn, skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ meɪd. "ði oʊl mɛn steɪ əweɪk, bʌt hæf kæn ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt ðəɹ fleɪmɪŋ səpoʊz tə də ɪf ðeɪ si sʌmbɑɾi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə skeɪl ðə blʌɾi wɔl, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf təɡɛðɝ kʊdn faɪɾ ɔf sɪks ʃɛpɝdz wɪð ə dɔɡ." eɪvinhə ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ əɾ ɪleɪn ən nɑɾəd.

"I don't naming know what I can do with them," Birgitte grumbled as a maid liveried in red-and-white took Elayne's cloak and gloves in the small entry hall. Small in terms of the Royal Palace. With gilded stand-lamps flickering between narrow, fluted white columns, it was half again the size of Matherin's main entry hall, though the ceiling was not so high. Another maid with the White Lion on the left breast of her dress, a girl not that much older than the boy who had tried to bring his horse inside, offered a ropework silver tray with tall cups of steaming spiced wine before simultaneous frowns from Aviendha and Birgitte made her shy back. "The flaming boys fall asleep if they're put on guard," Birgitte went on, scowling at the retreating maid. "The old men stay awake, but half can't remember what they're flaming supposed to do if they see somebody trying to scale the bloody wall, and the other half together couldn't fight off six shepherds with a dog." Aviendha raised an eyebrow at Elayne and nodded.

"ðeɪ ɑɹən hɪɹ tə faɪt," ɪleɪn ɹimaɪndəɾ əm əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd daʊn ə blu-taɪl kɔɹəɾɝ laɪnd wɪð mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps ən ɪnleɪd tʃɛsts, bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ ən ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən spɹɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə fju peɪsɪz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ən bɪhaɪnd. laɪt, ʃi θɔt, aɪ wʊdn əv teɪkən ðə waɪn! hɝ hɛd paʊndɪɾ ɪn ɹɪðəm wɪð bɝdʒɪts, ən ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ tɛmpəl, wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi ʃəɾ ɔɹɾɝ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ tə ɡoʊ faɪn hilɪŋ ɪmiɾiətli.

"They aren't here to fight," Elayne reminded them as they started down a blue-tiled corridor lined with mirrored stand-lamps and inlaid chests, Birgitte and Aviendha on either side of her and the Guardswomen spreading out a few paces ahead of them and behind. Light, she thought, I wouldn't have taken the wine! Her head pounded in rhythm with Birgitte's, and she touched her temple, wondering whether she should order her Warder to go find Healing immediately.

bɝdʒɪt hæɾ ʌðɝ aɪdiəz, ðoʊ. ʃi aɪd ɹæsɔɹiə ən ði ʌðɝz ɪn fɹʌnt, ðən lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən moʊʃən ðoʊz fɑloʊɪŋ tə fɔl bæk ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. ðət wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ. ʃi hæd hændpɪkt ɛvɹi læst wʊmən ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz, ən ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd ðɛm. ivən soʊ, wən ʃi spoʊk ɪt wɑz ɪn ə hɝid nɪɹ-wɪspɝ, bɛndɪŋ əɹ hɛd kloʊs tə ɪleɪn. "sʌmθɪŋ hæpən dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ jə ɹɪtɝnd. aɪ wɑz æskɪŋ sumeɪkoʊ ɪf ʃid hil mi bɪfɔɹ jə ɡɑt bæk, ən ʃi sʌɾənli fɛl oʊvɝ ɪn ə feɪnt. hɝ aɪz dʒʌst ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn əɹ hɛd, ən daʊn ʃi wɛnt. ɪɾ ɪzən oʊnli hɝ. noʊbɑdi wɪl ədmɪɾ ə fleɪmɪŋ θɪŋ, nɑt tə mi, bʌt ði ʌðɝ kɪn aɪv sin əv bɪn dʒʌmpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ blʌɾi skɪnz, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, tu. nɑt wʌn ə ðɛm kəd spɪɾ ɪf ʃi hæd tə. jə wɝ bæk bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd faɪn ə sɪstɝ, bʌɾ aɪ səspɛk ðeɪd ɡɪmi ðə fɪʃ aɪ, tu. ðəl tɛl ju, ðoʊ."

Birgitte had other ideas, though. She eyed Rasoria and the others in front, then looked over her shoulder and motioned those following to fall back a little more. That was strange. She had handpicked every last woman in the Guards, and she trusted them. Even so, when she spoke it was in a hurried near-whisper, bending her head close to Elayne. "Something happened just before you returned. I was asking Sumeko if she'd Heal me before you got back, and she suddenly fell over in a faint. Her eyes just rolled up in her head, and down she went. It isn't only her. Nobody will admit a flaming thing, not to me, but the other Kin I've seen have been jumping out of their bloody skins, and the Windfinders, too. Not one of them could spit if she had to. You were back before I could find a sister, but I suspect they'd give me the fish eye, too. They'll tell you, though."

ðə pæləs ɹikwaɪɝd ðə pɑpjəleɪʃən ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ vɪlədʒ tə kip ɹʌnɪŋ, ən sɝvəns hæd bɪɡʌn tə əpɪɹ, lɪvɹid mɛn ən wɪmən skɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz, flæɾənɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛns ðə wɔlz əɹ dʌkɪŋ ɪndə kɹɔsɪŋ hɔlweɪz tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ ɪleɪnz ɛskɔɹt, soʊ ʃi ɪkspleɪn ðə lɪɾəl ʃi nu ɪn əz sɑft ə vɔɪs ən əz fju wɝdz əz pɑsəbəl. səm ɹumɝz ʃi dɪd nɑt maɪn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə stʃɹits, ən ɪnɛvəɾəbli ɛɹəmɪlə, bʌt teɪlz ə ɹænd kəd bi əz bæɾ əz teɪlz ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ wɝ twɪstəd θɹu ə fju ɹɛtɛlɪŋz. wɝs, ɪn ə weɪ. noʊ wʌn wəd bɪliv ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ əɹ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn əz ə pʌpət. "ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt," ʃi fɪnɪʃt, "ɪts nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð əs hɪɹ." ʃi θɔt ʃi saʊndəd vɛɹi kənvɪnsɪŋ, vɛɹi kul ən dɪtætʃt, bʌɾ eɪvinhə ɹitʃt aʊt tə skwiz əɹ hænd, fəɹ ən il əz mʌtʃ əz ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ hʌɡ wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl tə si, ən bɝdʒɪts sɪmpəθi flʌɾəd θɹu ðə bɑnd. ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən kəməzɝeɪʃən; ɪt wɑz ðə ʃɛɹd filɪŋ ʌv ə wʊmən u hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sʌfɝd ðə lɔs ʃi hɝsɛlf fɪɹɾ ən mɔɹ. ɡeɪɾəl keɪn wɑz lɔs tə bɝdʒɪɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf i wɝ dɛd, ən ɑn tɑp ə ðæt, hɝ mɛmɹiz ə hɝ pæs laɪvz wɝ feɪɾɪŋ. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ klɪɹli bɪfɔɹ ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən nɑɾ ɔl ə ðæt. səm naɪts, ðə fɪɹ ðət ɡeɪɾəl wəd feɪd fɹəm əɹ mɛmɹi, tu, ðət ʃi wəd luz ɛni ɹimɛmbɹəns ʌv æktʃəli  hævɪŋ noʊn ən lʌv hɪm, lɛft əɹ əneɪbəl tə slip əntɪl ʃi dʒɹæŋk əz mʌtʃ bɹændi əz ʃi kəd hoʊld. ðət wɑz ə pʊɹ səluʃən, ən ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi kəɾ ɔfɝ ə bɛɾɝ, jɛt ʃi nu hɝ oʊn mɛmɹiz ə ɹænd wəd nɑt daɪ əntɪl ʃi dɪd, ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ðə hɔɹɝ ə noʊɪŋ ðoʊz mɛmɹiz maɪt liv hɝ. stɪl, ʃi hoʊp sʌmwʌn hil bɝdʒɪts mɔɹnɪŋ-æftɝ hɛd sun, bɪfɔɹ əɹ oʊn splɪɾ oʊpən laɪk ən oʊvɝ-ɹaɪp mɛlən. hɝ əbɪləɾi wɪð hilɪŋ fɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə tæsk, ən eɪvinhəz wɑz noʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ. dɪspaɪt ði ɪmoʊʃən ʃi kəd fil ɪn bɝdʒɪt, ði ʌðɝ wʊmən kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð ən ʌnkənsɝnd. "ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ʃi mʌɾɝd dʒɹaɪli. ən sɔfli. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə neɪm tə bændi əbaʊt. "wɛl, əz lɔŋ ɪts əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs, wɝ blʌɾi ɔl ɹaɪt." ə ɡɹʌn ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ə læf ɡeɪv əɹ ðə laɪ. bʌt ðɛn, ɔlðoʊ bɝdʒɪt sɛd ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ə soʊlʒɝ bɪfɔɹ, ʃi hæɾ ə soʊlʒɝz vju. lɔŋ ɑdz wɝ juʒəwəli ði oʊnli ɑdz jə kəd faɪnd, bʌt jə stɪl hæd tə ɡɛt ðə dʒɑb dʌn. "aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt ðeɪ θɪŋk ʌv ɪt?" ʃi æɾəd, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd dʒʌst stɛpt aʊɾ ʌv ə kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ.

The palace required the population of a large village to keep running, and servants had begun to appear, liveried men and women scurrying along the corridors, flattening themselves against the walls or ducking into crossing hallways to make room for Elayne's escort, so she explained the little she knew in as soft a voice and as few words as possible. Some rumors she did not mind reaching the streets, and inevitably Arymilla, but tales of Rand could be as bad as tales of the Forsaken by the time they were twisted through a few retellings. Worse, in a way. No one would believe the Forsaken were trying to put her on the throne as a puppet. "In any event," she finished, "it's nothing to do with us here." She thought she sounded very convincing, very cool and detached, but Aviendha reached out to squeeze her hand, for an Aiel as much as a comforting hug with so many people to see, and Birgitte's sympathy flooded through the bond. It was more than commiseration; it was the shared feeling of a woman who had already suffered the loss she herself feared and more. Gaidal Cain was lost to Birgitte as surely as if he were dead, and on top of that, her memories of her past lives were fading. She remembered almost nothing clearly before the founding of the White Tower, and not all of that. Some nights, the fear that Gaidal would fade from her memory, too, that she would lose any remembrance of actually having known and loved him, left her unable to sleep until she drank as much brandy as she could hold. That was a poor solution, and Elayne wished she could offer a better, yet she knew her own memories of Rand would not die until she did, and she could not imagine the horror of knowing those memories might leave her. Still, she hoped someone Healed Birgitte's morning-after head soon, before her own split open like an over-ripe melon. Her ability with Healing fell short of the task, and Aviendha's was no stronger. Despite the emotion she could feel in Birgitte, the other woman kept her face smooth and unconcerned. "The Forsaken," she muttered dryly. And softly. That was not a name to bandy about. "Well, as long as it has nothing to do with us, we're bloody all right." A grunt that might have been a laugh gave her the lie. But then, although Birgitte said she had never been a soldier before, she had a soldier's view. Long odds were usually the only odds you could find, but you still had to get the job done. "I wonder what they think of it?" she added, nodding toward the four Aes Sedai who had just stepped out of a crossing corridor down the hallway.

vændin, mɛɝɪlɪl, sɝaɪðə ən kɛɝin hæd ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ əz ðeɪ wɔkt, əɹ ɹæðɝ, ðə læs θɹi wɝ klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn vændin, linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ ən tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɝdʒən dʒɛstʃɝz ðət meɪd ðə fɹɪnʒɪz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɔlz sweɪ. vændin ɡlaɪɾɪd əlɔŋ sloʊli əz ɪf ʃi wɝ əloʊn, peɪɪŋ noʊ hid. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn slɛndɝ, bʌɾ əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin dʒɹɛs, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð flaʊɝz ɑn ðə slivz ən ʃoʊldɝz, hʌŋ ɑn əɹ əz ðoʊ meɪd fəɹ ə staʊɾɝ wʊmən, ən ðə waɪt hɛɹ ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk simd ɪn niɾ ʌv ə bɹʌʃ. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz blik, bʌt ðət maɪɾ əv hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɝ seɪɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn dʒɔɪləs ɛvɝ sɪns əɹ sɪstɝz mɝɾɝ. ɪleɪn wʊɾə weɪdʒɝd ðət dʒɹɛs hæd bɪlɔŋ tə æɾɪliz. sɪns ðə mɝɾɝ, vændin wɔɹ əɹ sɪstɝz kloʊðz mɔɹ ɔfən ðən əɹ oʊn. nɑt ðət ðəɾ əkaʊntəd fəɹ ðə fɪt. ðə tu wɪmən hæd bɪn ʌv ə saɪz, bʌt vændinz æpətaɪt fəɹ fud hæd daɪd wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ. hɝ teɪs fəɹ moʊs θɪŋz sim tə hæv daɪd ðɛn.

Vandene, Merilille, Sareitha and Careane had their heads together as they walked, or rather, the last three were clustered around Vandene, leaning toward her and talking with urgent gestures that made the fringes on their shawls sway. Vandene glided along slowly as if she were alone, paying no heed. She had always been slender, but her dark green dress, embroidered with flowers on the sleeves and shoulders, hung on her as though made for a stouter woman, and the white hair gathered at the nape of her neck seemed in need of a brush. Her expression was bleak, but that might have had nothing to do with whatever the other sisters were saying. She had been joyless ever since her sister's murder. Elayne would have wagered that dress had belonged to Adeleas. Since the murder, Vandene wore her sister's clothes more often than her own. Not that that accounted for the fit. The two women had been of a size, but Vandene's appetite for food had died with her sister. Her taste for most things seemed to have died then.

sɝaɪðə, ə bɹaʊn huz dɑɹk skwɛɹ feɪs wɑz nɑt jɛt tʌtʃt wɪð eɪɡləsnəs, sɔ ɪleɪn dʒʌs ðɛn, ən pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn vændinz ɑɹm əz ɪf tə dʒɹɔ hɝ ʌp ðə kɔɹəɾɝ. vændin bɹʌʃt ðə tɛɹən wʊmənz hæn əweɪ ən ɡlaɪɾɪd ɑn wɪð ðə mɛɹəst ɡlæns əɾ ɪleɪn, dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɑn əlɔŋ ðə hɔlweɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm aʊɾ ʌv. tu wɪmən ɪn nɑvəs waɪt, hu hæd bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ ði ʌðɝz əɾ ə ɹɪspɛkfəl dɪstəns, ɔfɝd kwɪk kɝtsiz tə ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ sɪstɝz ən heɪsən æftɝ vændin. mɛɝɪlɪl, ə taɪni wʊmən ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ðət meɪɾ əɹ kɛɹhinɪn pælnəs sim laɪk aɪvɝi, stɛɹɾ əz ɪf ʃi maɪt fɑloʊ.

Sareitha, a Brown whose dark square face was not yet touched with agelessness, saw Elayne just then, and put a hand on Vandene's arm as if to draw her up the corridor. Vandene brushed the Tairen woman's hand away and glided on with the merest glance at Elayne, disappearing on along the hallway they had come out of. Two women in novice white, who had been following the others at a respectful distance, offered quick curtsies to the remaining sisters and hastened after Vandene. Merilille, a tiny woman in dark gray that made her Cairhienin paleness seem like ivory, stared as if she might follow.

kɛɝin ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɑn ʃoʊldɝz waɪɾɝ ðən ðoʊz ə mɛni mɛn ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd kwaɪət wɝdz wɪð sɝaɪðə. ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tɝn tə miɾ ɪleɪn əz ʃi əpɹoʊtʃt, meɪkɪŋ əɹ kɝtsiz ɔlmoʊst əz dip əz ðə nɑvəsɪz hæd ɡɪvən ðɛm. mɛɝɪlɪl noʊɾəst ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ən blɪŋkt, ðən noʊɾəst ɪleɪn ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. hɝ kɝtsi mætʃt ðə nɑvəsɪz'. mɛɝɪlɪl hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl fəɹ oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, kɛɝin fəɹ mɔɹ ðən fɪfti, ən ivən sɝaɪðə hæd wɔɹn ɪt lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, bʌt stændɪŋ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛnt wɪð stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, ən nʌn ə ðiz θɹi wɑz mɔɹ ðən mɪɾəlɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ əmʌŋ sɪstɝz. ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪz, ɪnkɹist stʃɹɛŋkθ ɡeɪv, ɪf nɑɾ ɪnkɹist wɪzdəm, ət list ɪnkɹist weɪt tə jəɹ əpɪnjənz. wɪð ə səfɪʃənt ɡæp, ðoʊz əpɪnjənz bɪkeɪm kəmænz. səmtaɪmz, ɪleɪn θɔt ðə kɪnz weɪ wɑz bɛɾɝ.

Careane adjusted her green-fringed shawl on shoulders wider than those of many men and exchanged quiet words with Sareitha. The pair of them turned to meet Elayne as she approached, making her curtsies almost as deep as the novices had given them. Merilille noticed the Guardswomen and blinked, then noticed Elayne and gave a start. Her curtsy matched the novices'. Merilille had worn the shawl for over a hundred years, Careane for more than fifty, and even Sareitha had worn it longer than Elayne Trakand, but standing among Aes Sedai went with strength in the Power, and none of these three was more than middling strong among sisters. In Aes Sedai eyes, increased strength gave, if not increased wisdom, at least increased weight to your opinions. With a sufficient gap, those opinions became commands. Sometimes, Elayne thought the Kin's way was better.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz," ʃi sɛd bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd spik, "bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ wi kən də əbaʊɾ ɪt, soʊ wi maɪɾ əz wɛl kwɪt wɝiɪŋ. wɪv ɪnʌf ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv əs wɪθaʊt fɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ θɪŋz wi kæn əfɛkt."

"I don't know what it is," she said before any of the other Aes Sedai could speak, "but there is nothing we can do about it, so we might as well quit worrying. We have enough right in front of us without fretting over things we can't affect."

ɹæsɔɹiə hæf-tɝn əɹ hɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən pleɪnli wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt ʃi hæd mɪst, bʌt ðə wɝdz smuðd ði æŋzaɪəɾi fɹəm sɝaɪðəz dɑɹk aɪz. pɝhæps nɑt fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ, sɪns əɹ hænz muvd əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə smuð əɹ bɹaʊn skɝts, jɛt ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə lɛɾ ʌv ə sɪstɝ u stʊɾ əz haɪ əz ɪleɪn. səmtaɪmz, ðəɹ wɝ ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə stændɪŋ haɪ ɪnʌf ðət jə kəd kwɛl əbdʒɛkʃənz wɪð ə sɛntəns. kɛɝin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹiɡeɪn sɝɛnəɾi, ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ lɔst ɪt. ɪt sæɾ izəli ɑn hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ bɛɹəl-slæʃt sɪlks ən smuð, eɪdʒləs kɑpɝi feɪs.

Rasoria half-turned her head, frowning and plainly wondering what she had missed, but the words smoothed the anxiety from Sareitha's dark eyes. Perhaps not from the rest of her, since her hands moved as if she wanted to smooth her brown skirts, yet she was willing to follow the lead of a sister who stood as high as Elayne. Sometimes, there were advantages to standing high enough that you could quell objections with a sentence. Careane had already regained serenity, if she had ever lost it. It sat easily on her, though she looked more like a wagon driver than an Aes Sedai despite her beryl-slashed silks and smooth, ageless coppery face.

bʌt ðɛn, ɡɹinz juʒəwəli wɝ meɪɾ ə tʌfɝ stʌf ðən bɹaʊnz. mɛɝɪlɪl dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɔl sɝin. waɪɾ aɪz ən hæf-pɑɹɾəd lɪps ɡeɪv əɹ ði əpɪɹəns ə stɑɹɾəlmənt. ðət wɑz juʒəwəl fəɹ hɝ, ðoʊ.

But then, Greens usually were made of tougher stuff than Browns. Merilille did not look at all serene. Wide eyes and half-parted lips gave her the appearance of startlement. That was usual for her, though.

ɪleɪn kəntɪnjuɾ əlɔŋ ðə hɔlweɪ, hoʊpɪŋ ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs, bʌt mɛɝɪlɪl fɛl ɪn bɪsaɪd bɝdʒɪt. ðə ɡɹeɪ ʃʊɾə teɪkən pɹaɪməsi əmʌŋ ðə θɹi, bʌt ʃi hæd dɪvɛləpt ə tɛndənsi tə weɪt fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du, ən ʃi ʃɪftəɾ oʊvɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd wən sɝaɪðə pəlaɪtli æsk bɝdʒɪt tə ɡɪv əɹ ɹum. ðə sɪstɝz wɝ ənfeɪlɪŋli kɝɾiəs tə ɪleɪnz wɔɹɾɝ wən ʃi wɑz æktɪŋ əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl. ɪt wɑz bɝdʒɪɾ əz wɔɹɾɝ ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ. eɪvinhə ɹəsiv noʊ sətʃ səvɪləɾi fɹəm kɛɝin, hu ɛlboʊɾ ɪn bɪtwin əɹ ən ɪleɪn. ɛniwʌn nɑt tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz ə waɪldɝ baɪ dɛfənɪʃən, ən kɛɝin dɪspaɪzd waɪldɝz. eɪvinhə pɝst əɹ lɪps ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt dʒɹɔ hɝ bɛl naɪf əɹ ivən sədʒɛs ðət ʃi maɪt, fəɹ wɪtʃ ɪleɪn wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. hɝ fɝst-sɪstɝ kəd bi . . . pɹɪsɪpɪteɪt, ət taɪmz. ɑn sɛkən θɔt, ʃi wʊɾə fɝɡɪvən ə lɪɾəl heɪstinəs fɹəm eɪvinhə ɹaɪt ðɛn. kʌstəm fɝbeɪd ɹudnəs təwɔɹɾ ənʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌndɝ ɛni sɝkəmstænsəz, bʌɾ eɪvinhə cʊɾə ɡɹaʊl θɹɛts ən weɪvd əɹ naɪf tə hɝ hɑɹts kɑntɛnt. ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə θɹisəm liv, ivən ɪf ɪn ə tɪzi. kɛɝin dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs ðə kul ɡɹin ɡeɪz mɑɹkɪŋ hɝ.

Elayne continued along the hallway, hoping they would go about their business, but Merilille fell in beside Birgitte. The Gray should have taken primacy among the three, but she had developed a tendency to wait for someone to tell her what to do, and she shifted over without a word when Sareitha politely asked Birgitte to give her room. The sisters were unfailingly courteous to Elayne's Warder when she was acting as Captain-General. It was Birgitte as Warder they tried to ignore. Aviendha received no such civility from Careane, who elbowed in between her and Elayne. Anyone not trained in the White Tower was a wilder by definition, and Careane despised wilders. Aviendha pursed her lips though she did not draw her belt knife or even suggest that she might, for which Elayne was grateful. Her first-sister could be . . . precipitate, at times. On second thought, she would have forgiven a little hastiness from Aviendha right then. Custom forbade rudeness toward another Aes Sedai under any circumstances, but Aviendha could have growled threats and waved her knife to her heart's content. That might have been enough to make the threesome leave, even if in a tizzy. Careane did not seem to notice the cool green gaze marking her.

"aɪ toʊl mɛɝɪlɪl ən sɝaɪðə ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ wi kəd də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. "bʌt ʃʊdnt wi bi ɹɛɾi tə fli ɪf ɪt kʌmz kloʊsɝ? ðɛɹz noʊ ʃeɪm flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ðæt. ivən lɪŋkt, wi wəd bi mɔθs faɪɾɪŋ ə fɔɹəs faɪɝ. vændin wʊdn bɑðɝ tə lɪsən."

"I told Merilille and Sareitha it was nothing we could do anything about," she said calmly. "But shouldn't we be ready to flee if it comes closer? There's no shame flying from that. Even linked, we would be moths fighting a forest fire. Vandene wouldn't bother to listen."

"wi ɹɪli ʃəd meɪk səm sɔɹɾ ə pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz, ɪleɪn," sɝaɪðə mɝmɝɾ æbsənli, əz ɪf meɪkɪŋ lɪsts ɪn əɹ hɛd. "ɪts wən jə doʊn meɪk plænz ðət jə wɪʃ jə hæd. ðəɹ ɑɹ ə nʌmbɝ ə vɑljumz ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi hɪɹ ðət mʌsnt bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd. aɪ bɪliv sɛvɹəl kæn bi faʊn ɪn ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi." "jɛs." mɛɝɪlɪlz vɔɪs wɑz bɹɛθləs, ən əz æŋkʃəs əz əɹ lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz. "jɛs, wi ɹɪli ʃəd bi ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ. pɝhæps. . . . pɝhæps wi ʃəd nɑt weɪt. ʃʊɹli ɡoʊɪŋ fɹəm nəsɛsəɾi wəd nɑt vaɪəleɪɾ əɹ əɡɹimənt. aɪm ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd nɑt." oʊnli bɝdʒɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət hɝ, bʌt ʃi flɪntʃt.

"We really should make some sort of preparations, Elayne," Sareitha murmured absently, as if making lists in her head. "It's when you don't make plans that you wish you had. There are a number of volumes in the library here that mustn't be left behind. I believe several can't be found in the Tower library." "Yes." Merilille's voice was breathless, and as anxious as her large dark eyes. "Yes, we really should be ready to go. Perhaps. . . . Perhaps we should not wait. Surely going from necessity would not violate our agreement. I am sure it would not." Only Birgitte as much as glanced at her, but she flinched.

"ɪf wi də ɡoʊ," kɛɝin sɛɾ əz ɪf mɛɝɪlɪl hæd nɑt spoʊkən, "wil əv tə teɪk ɔl ə ðə kɪn wɪð ʌs. əlaʊ ðɛm tə skæɾɝ, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz wʌt ðəl də əɹ wən wɪl ɛvɝ kætʃ əm əɡɛn, ɪspɛʃli naʊ ðət səm əv lɝn tə tʃɹævəl." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɪɾɝnəs ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, ðoʊ oʊnli ɪleɪn əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə pæləs kəd tʃɹævəl. ɪt sim tə meɪk ə dɪfɝəns tə kɛɝin ðət ðə kɪnswɪmən hæd bɪɡʌn ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ivən ɪf moʊs hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊɾ ən ə fju hæd ɹʌn əweɪ.

"If we do go," Careane said as if Merilille had not spoken, "we'll have to take all of the Kin with us. Allow them to scatter, and the Light only knows what they'll do or when we will ever catch them again, especially now that some have learned to Travel." There was no bitterness in her voice, though only Elayne among the sisters in the palace could Travel. It seemed to make a difference to Careane that the Kinswomen had begun in the White Tower, even if most had been put out and a few had run away.

ʃi hæɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪd noʊ fjuɝ ðən fɔɹ ə ðɛm hɝsɛlf, ɪnkluɾɪŋ wʌn ɹʌnəweɪ. ət lis ðeɪ wɝ nɑt waɪldɝz.

She had identified no fewer than four of them herself, including one runaway. At least they were not wilders.

sɝaɪðəz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ðoʊ. ɪt weɪɾ ɑn əɹ ðət sɛvɹəl kɪnswɪmən kəd wiv ɡeɪtweɪz, ən ʃi hæd vɛɹi dɪfɹənt noʊʃənz ə ðə kɪn. nɔɹməli, ʃi lɪməɾəd əɹ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə ði əkeɪʒənəl fɹaʊn əɹ dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ɡɹɪmɑs, sɪns ɪleɪn hæd meɪɾ əɹ oʊn vjuz klɪɹ, bʌt ðə stʃɹɛs ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sim tə hæv lusən əɹ tʌŋ. "wi də ɪndid nid tə teɪk əm wɪð ʌs," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kʌɾɪŋ toʊn, "ɛls ðəl ɔl bi kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ əz sun əz ðəɹ aʊɾ ʌv əɹ saɪt. ɛni wʊmən u meɪnteɪnz ʃi wɑz pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ wɪl kleɪm ɛniθɪŋ!

Sareitha's mouth tightened, though. It weighed on her that several Kinswomen could weave gateways, and she had very different notions of the Kin. Normally, she limited her objections to the occasional frown or disparaging grimace, since Elayne had made her own views clear, but the stress of the morning seemed to have loosened her tongue. "We do indeed need to take them with us," she said in a cutting tone, "else they'll all be claiming to be Aes Sedai as soon as they're out of our sight. Any woman who maintains she was put out of the Tower over three hundred years ago will claim anything!

ðeɪ nid tə bi kɛpt ʌndɝ ə kloʊs wɑtʃ, ɪf jə æsk mi, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz ðeɪ pliz, moʊst ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz u kən tʃɹævəl. ðeɪ meɪ hæv ɡɔn wɛɹ jə toʊld əm ən kʌm bæk soʊ fɑɹ, ɪleɪn, bʌt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðɛm dʌzn ɹɪtɝn? mɑɹk maɪ wɝdz, wʌns wʌn ə ðɛm ɪskeɪps, ʌðɝz wɪl fɑloʊ, ən wɪl əv ə mɛs ɑn əɹ hænz wɪl nɛvɝ klin ʌp."

They need to be kept under a close watch, if you ask me, instead of going about as they please, most especially those who can Travel. They may have gone where you told them and come back so far, Elayne, but how long before one of them doesn't return? Mark my words, once one of them escapes, others will follow, and we will have a mess on our hands we'll never clean up."

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ əs tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli, əz mʌtʃ fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz əz fəɹ ðə sɪstɝz. ðət dɪstən bikən wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə seɪm spɑt wɛɹ ʃi hæd fɝst sɛnst ɪt, ən ɪf ɪt dɪd muv, ðə tʃæns sim smɔl ðəɾ ɪt wəd muv təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs æktʃəli  kʌm ðɛɹ, bʌɾ ə ɹumɝ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ plænɪŋ flaɪt maɪt bi ɪnʌf tə ɛndʒɛndɝ ə stæmpid, mɑbz klɔɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ðə ɡeɪts əhɛɾ ʌv wʌtɛvɝ kəd fɹaɪɾən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ɑɹmi sækɪŋ ðə sɪɾi wəd nɑt kɪl əz mɛni. ən ðiz θɹi tʃæɾɝd əweɪ əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wʌn tə hɪɹ bʌt ðə wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz! ðəɹ wɑz səm ɪkskjus fəɹ mɛɝɪlɪl, bʌt nɑt ði ʌðɝz. "wi wɪl ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ, əz ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ əz kəmændəd, əntɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn kəmænz ʌðɝwaɪz. ðə kɪnswɪmən wɪl kəntɪnju tə ɹəsiv ɛvɹi kɝɾəsi əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ wɛlkəm bæk ɪndə ðə taʊɝ, ən ðəɾ ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪnz kəmænd, tu, əz jə vɛɹi wɛl noʊ. jəl wɪl kəntɪnju titʃɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ən ɡoʊ əbaʊt jəɹ lɪvz əz ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɹ ɑɹ səpoʊz tə dil wɪð pipəlz fɪɹz ən suð ðɛm, nɑt spɹɛd sɛnsləs ɡɑsəp ən pænɪk." wɛl, pɝhæps ʃi hæd bɪn ə tʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən fɝm. sɝaɪðə pʊɾ əɹ ɡeɪz ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz laɪk ə ɹɪbjuk nɑvəs. mɛɝɪlɪl flɪntʃt əɡɛn ət mɛnʃən ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, bʌt ðət wɑz tə bi ɪkspɛktəd. ði ʌðɝz ɡeɪv lɛsənz, bʌt ðə si foʊk hɛl mɛɝɪlɪl əz taɪtli əz ðeɪ dɪd wʌn ə ðɛɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz. ʃi slɛpt ɪn ðɛɹ kɔɹɾɝz ən nɔɹməli wɑz nɑt sin wɪθaʊt tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ðɛm, ən əɹ tʃɹeɪlɪŋ mikli ət ðɛɹ hilz. ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɛniθɪŋ lɛs ðən miknəs fɹəm hɝ.

"There is no reason for us to go anywhere," Elayne said firmly, as much for the Guards as for the sisters. That distant beacon was still in the same spot where she had first sensed it, and if it did move, the chance seemed small that it would move toward Caemlyn, much less actually come there, but a rumor that Aes Sedai were planning flight might be enough to engender a stampede, mobs clawing to reach the gates ahead of whatever could frighten Aes Sedai. An army sacking the city would not kill as many. And these three chattered away as if there were no one to hear but the wall hangings! There was some excuse for Merilille, but not the others. "We will remain here, as the Amyrlin Seat has commanded, until the Amyrlin commands otherwise. The Kinswomen will continue to receive every courtesy until they are welcomed back into the Tower, and that is the Amyrlin's command, too, as you very well know. And you will continue teaching the Windfinders and go about your lives as Aes Sedai should. We are supposed to deal with people's fears and soothe them, not spread senseless gossip and panic." Well, perhaps she had been a touch more than firm. Sareitha put her gaze on the floor tiles like a rebuked novice. Merilille flinched again at mention of the Windfinders, but that was to be expected. The others gave lessons, but the Sea Folk held Merilille as tightly as they did one of their apprentices. She slept in their quarters and normally was not seen without two or three of them, and her trailing meekly at their heels. They refused to accept anything less than meekness from her.

"ʌv kɔɹs, ɪleɪn," kɛɝin sɛd heɪstəli. "ʌv kɔɹs. nʌn ʌv əs wəd sədʒɛs dɪsəbɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪn." hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹmz, simɪŋli ɑkjəpaɪd wɪð sɛɾɪŋ ɪt dʒʌst soʊ. ʃi dɪd spɛɹ ə pɪɾiɪŋ lʊk fəɹ mɛɝɪlɪl. "bʌt spikɪŋ ə ðə si foʊk, kəd jə tɛl vændin tə teɪk əɹ ʃɛɹ ə ðə lɛsənz?" wən ɪleɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ, hɝ vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ən ɛdʒ ðət wʊɾə bɪn kɔl sʌlən ɪn ɛniwʌn nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ʃi sɛz ʃiz tu bɪzi wɪð ðoʊz tu ɹʌnəweɪz, bʌt ʃi faɪnz ɪnʌf taɪm tə kip mi tɔkɪŋ səm naɪts əntɪl aɪm hæf əslip. ðət pɛɹ ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi soʊ kaʊd ðeɪ wʊdn skwik ɪf ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz kɑt faɪɝ. ðeɪ doʊnt niɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən. ʃi kəd teɪk əɹ pɔɹʃən ə titʃɪŋ ðoʊz kɝst waɪldɝz. vændin nidz tə stɑɹt bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu!"

"Of course, Elayne," Careane said hastily. "Of course. None of us would suggest disobeying the Amyrlin." Hesitating, she adjusted her green-fringed shawl over her arms, seemingly occupied with setting it just so. She did spare a pitying look for Merilille. "But speaking of the Sea Folk, could you tell Vandene to take her share of the lessons?" When Elayne said nothing, her voice took on an edge that would have been called sullen in anyone not Aes Sedai. "She says she's too busy with those two runaways, but she finds enough time to keep me talking some nights until I'm half asleep. That pair is already so cowed they wouldn't squeak if their dresses caught fire. They don't need her attention. She could take her portion of teaching those cursed wilders. Vandene needs to start behaving as an Aes Sedai, too!"

stændɪŋ əɹ noʊ, ɹibjuk əɹ noʊ, ʃi ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə beɪlfəl ɡlɛɹ ðət tʊk əɹ ə moʊmən tə smʌðɝ.

Standing or no, rebuke or no, she gave Elayne a baleful glare that took her a moment to smother.

ɪleɪn hæd bɪn ðə wʌn u meɪd ðə bɑɹɡən ðət lɛd tə ɛɛs sədaɪ hævɪŋ tə titʃ wɪndfɪndɝz, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd mænədʒ tə mɪs ɡɪvɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ə lɛsənz, kleɪmɪŋ ðə pɹɛs ʌv ʌðɝ, mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt duɾiz. bɪsaɪdz, ðə si foʊk sɔ ə ʃɔɹbaʊn titʃɝ əz ə haɪɹəlɪŋ, ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ə haɪɹəlɪŋ wɪð lɛs stændɪŋ ðən ə skʌljən ət ðæt. ə skʌljən u maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə tʃiɾ ɑn əɹ leɪbɝ.

Elayne had been the one who made the bargain that led to Aes Sedai having to teach Windfinders, but so far she herself had managed to miss giving more than a handful of lessons, claiming the press of other, more important duties. Besides, the Sea Folk saw a shorebound teacher as a hireling, even an Aes Sedai, and a hireling with less standing than a scullion at that. A scullion who might try to cheat on her labor.

ʃi stɪl θɔt nɪneɪiv hæd ɡɔn əweɪ dʒʌs tə əvɔɪd ɡɪvɪŋ ðoʊz lɛsənz. sɝɾənli noʊ wʌn ɪkspɛktəd tə ɛn ʌp ɪn mɛɝɪlɪlz steɪt, bʌɾ ivən ə fju aʊɝz əɾ ə taɪm wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf.

She still thought Nynaeve had gone away just to avoid giving those lessons. Certainly no one expected to end up in Merilille's state, but even a few hours at a time was bad enough.

"oʊ, noʊ, kɛɝin," sɝaɪðə pʊɾ ɪn, stɪl əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪleɪnz aɪ. ən mɛɝɪlɪlz. ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən, ðə ɡɹeɪ hæd ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf ɪndə ðɪs fɪks ən ðʌs dɪzɝvd wʌt keɪm ʌv ɪt, bʌt ʃi dɪd tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə ɹʌb sɔlt ɪn ðə wunz. "vændin ɪz dɪstʃɹɔɾ oʊvɝ əɹ sɪstɝ, ən kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə hɛlp əɹ ɑkjəpaɪ hɝ maɪnd." wʌtɛvɝ ʃi θɔɾ ə ði ʌðɝ kɪn, ʃi æksɛptɪd ðət zɛɹjə wɑz ə ɹʌnəweɪ, əz ʃi hæd tə, sɪns zɛɹjə wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz kɛɝin hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd, ən ɪf kɝstʃən mʌs bi ə laɪɝ, hɝ oʊn laɪ wəd meɪk əɹ peɪ ɪn fʊl fəɹ ðæt. ɹʌnəweɪz wɝ nɑt tʃɹiɾəd kaɪnli. "aɪ spɛn aʊɝz wɪð hɝ, tu, ən ʃi ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ tɔks ʌv ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ æɾɪliz. ɪts əz ɪf ʃi wɑns tə æd maɪ mɛmɹiz tə hɝ oʊn. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi nidz tə bi əlaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ taɪm əz ʃi nidz, ən ðoʊz tu kip əɹ fɹəm biɪŋ əloʊn tu ɔfən." ɡɪvɪŋ ɪleɪn ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns, ʃi dʒɹu bɹɛθ. "stɪl, titʃɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɪz sɝɾənli . . .

"Oh, no, Careane," Sareitha put in, still avoiding Elayne's eye. And Merilille's. In her opinion, the Gray had gotten herself into this fix and thus deserved what came of it, but she did try not to rub salt in the wounds. "Vandene is distraught over her sister, and Kirstian and Zarya help her occupy her mind." Whatever she thought of the other Kin, she accepted that Zarya was a runaway, as she had to, since Zarya was one of those Careane had recognized, and if Kirstian must be a liar, her own lie would make her pay in full for that. Runaways were not treated kindly. "I spend hours with her, too, and she almost never talks of anything but Adeleas. It's as if she wants to add my memories to her own. I think she needs to be allowed as much time as she needs, and those two keep her from being alone too often." Giving Elayne a sidelong glance, she drew breath. "Still, teaching the Windfinders is certainly . . .

tʃælənʒɪŋ. pɝhæps ən aʊɝ naʊ ən ðən wəd hɛlp pʊl əɹ aʊɾ ə dɪspɑndənsi, ɪf oʊnli baɪ meɪkɪŋ əɹ æŋɡɹi. doʊn jə əɡɹi, ɪleɪn? dʒʌst ən aʊɝ əɹ tu, naʊ ən ðɛn."

challenging. Perhaps an hour now and then would help pull her out of despondency, if only by making her angry. Don't you agree, Elayne? Just an hour or two, now and then."

"vændin wɪl bi əlaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ taɪm tə ɡɹiv fəɹ əɹ sɪstɝ əz ʃi nidz əɹ wɑns," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn lɛvəl toʊnz. "æn ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ dɪskʌʃən ʌv ɪt." kɛɝin saɪd hɛvəli ən ɹiɝeɪnʒd əɹ ʃɔl əɡɛn. sɝaɪðə saɪd feɪnli ən bɪɡæn twɪstɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ ə hɝ lɛf hænd. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd sɛnst əɹ mud, əɹ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət niðɝ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ənʌðɝ sɛʃən wɪð ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. mɛɝɪlɪlz pɝmənənli sɝpɹaɪzd ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt ðɛn, hɝ sɛʃənz wɪð ðə si foʊk læstəɾ ɔl deɪ ən ɔl naɪɾ ənlɛs ɪleɪn mænədʒ tə pɹaɪ hɝ əweɪ, ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ lɛs ən lɛs wɪlɪŋ tə lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɪleɪn pɹaɪd.

"Vandene will be allowed as much time to grieve for her sister as she needs or wants," Elayne said in level tones. "And there will be no more discussion of it." Careane sighed heavily and rearranged her shawl again. Sareitha sighed faintly and began twisting the Great Serpent ring on the forefinger of her left hand. Perhaps they had sensed her mood, or perhaps it was just that neither looked forward to another session with the Windfinders. Merilille's permanently surprised expression did not change, but then, her sessions with the Sea Folk lasted all day and all night unless Elayne managed to pry her away, and the Windfinders were becoming less and less willing to let her go no matter how Elayne pried.

ət list ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ kɝt wɪð ðə θɹi. ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt, ɪspɛʃli wɪð eɪvinhə ðɛɹ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ʃi wəd də ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ lɔst əɹ sɪstɝ. vændin wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli ɡɹivɪŋ fəɹ ə sɪstɝ, ʃi wɑz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ æɾɪlizəz mɝɾɝɝ, ən ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ daʊt ðət ðə kɪlɝ wɑz mɛɝɪlɪl ʃiændɪvɪn, kɛɝin fɹænzi əɹ sɝaɪðə toʊmɑɹz. wʌn ə ðɛm, əɹ wɝs, mɔɹ ðən wʌn. ðə tʃɑɹdʒ wɑz hɑɹd tə bɪliv ə mɛɝɪlɪl, ɪn əɹ pɹɛzən kəndɪʃən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi tə bɪliv ʌv ɛni sɪstɝ. əz bɝdʒɪt hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt, wʌn ə ðə wɝs dɑɹkfɹɛnz ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛt, dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wɑz ə maɪld-æz-mɪlk læɾ u dʒʌmpt ət laʊd nɔɪzɪz. ən pɔɪzən ən ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾiz wɔɾɝ səplaɪ. eɪvinhəz sədʒɛstʃən wɑz tə pʊɾ ɔl θɹi tə ðə kwɛstʃən, wɪtʃ hæd hɔɹəfaɪd bɝdʒɪt, bʌɾ eɪvinhə wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbli lɛs ɪn ɑ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən ʃi wʌns hæd bɪn. ðə pɹɑpɝ kɝɾəsiz mʌs bi meɪnteɪnd, əntɪl ðəɹ wɑz ɛvəɾəns tə kənvɪkt. ðən ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ kɝɾəsi əɾ ɔl.

At least she had managed to avoid being curt with the three. It took an effort, especially with Aviendha there. Elayne did not know what she would do if she ever lost her sister. Vandene was not only grieving for a sister, she was searching for Adeleas's murderer, and there could be no doubt that the killer was Merilille Ceandevin, Careane Fransi or Sareitha Tomares. One of them, or worse, more than one. The charge was hard to believe of Merilille, in her present condition, but it was not easy to believe of any sister. As Birgitte had pointed out, one of the worst Darkfriends she had ever met, during the Trolloc Wars, was a mild-as-milk lad who jumped at loud noises. And poisoned an entire city's water supply. Aviendha's suggestion was to put all three to the question, which had horrified Birgitte, but Aviendha was considerably less in awe of Aes Sedai than she once had been. The proper courtesies must be maintained, until there was evidence to convict. Then there would be no courtesy at all.

"oʊ," sɝaɪðə sɛd, bɹaɪɾənɪŋ sʌɾənli. "hɪɹz kæptən mɛlɝ. hi wɑz ə hɪɹoʊ əɡɛn waɪl jə wɝ ɡɔn, ɪleɪn." eɪvinhə ɡɹɪp ðə hɪlt ə hɝ bɛl naɪf, ən bɝdʒɪt stɪfənd. kɛɝinz feɪs wɛn vɛɹi stɪl, vɛɹi koʊld, ən ivən mɛɝɪlɪl mænədʒd ə dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ hoʊtʊɹ. niðɝ sɪstɝ meɪɾ ɛni sikɹəɾ ə hɝ dɪslaɪk fəɹ dɔɪlən mɛlɝ.

"Oh," Sareitha said, brightening suddenly. "Here's Captain Mellar. He was a hero again while you were gone, Elayne." Aviendha gripped the hilt of her belt knife, and Birgitte stiffened. Careane's face went very still, very cold, and even Merilille managed a disapproving hauteur. Neither sister made any secret of her dislike for Doilan Mellar.

wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs, hi wɑz nɑt pɹɪɾi, əɹ ivən hænsəm, jɛɾ i muvd wɪð ə sɔɝdzmənz laɪð ɡɹeɪs ðət spoʊk ə fɪzɪkəl stʃɹɛŋkθ. əz kæptən ʌv ɪleɪnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd, hi ɹeɪɾəd θɹi ɡoʊldən nɑts ə ɹæŋk, ən i wɔɹ əm sɑldɝd tə itʃ ʃoʊldɝ ə hɪz bɹaɪtli bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt. ən ɪɡnɝən əbzɝvɝ maɪɾ əv θɔɾ i aʊtʃɹæŋk bɝdʒɪt. ðə fɔlz ə snoʊ-waɪt leɪs əɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən ɹɪsts wɝ twaɪs əz θɪk ən twaɪs əz lɔŋ əz ðoʊz wɔɹn baɪ ɛni ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, bʌɾ i hæd lɛft ɔf ðə sæʃ əɡɛn, pɝhæps kəz ɪt wʊɾə əbskjʊɹd wʌn sɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊldən nɑts. hi kleɪm ðəɾ i wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪn laɪf ðən tə kəmæn əɹ bɑɾiɡɑɹd, jɛɾ i fɹikwənli tɔkt ə bæɾəlz i hæd fɔɾ əz ə mɝsənɛɹi. ɪt simd i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɑn ðə luzɪŋ saɪd, ən vɪktɝi hæɾ ɔfən kʌm fɹəm ɪz ənsʌŋ ɛfɝts ɑn ðə fild. hi swɛpt ɔf ɪz waɪt-plum hæɾ ɪn ə dip, flɝɪʃɪŋ baʊ, mænɪdʒɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd dɛfli wɪð wʌn hænd, ðən ɔfɝɾ ə slaɪtli lɛsɝ tə bɝdʒɪt wɪð ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ɪn səlut. ɪleɪn ɝeɪnʒd ə smaɪl ɑn əɹ feɪs. "sɝaɪðə sɛz jə wɝ ə hɪɹoʊ əɡɛn, kæptən mɛlɝ. haʊ soʊ?"

With a narrow face, he was not pretty, or even handsome, yet he moved with a swordsman's lithe grace that spoke of physical strength. As Captain of Elayne's bodyguard, he rated three golden knots of rank, and he wore them soldered to each shoulder of his brightly burnished breastplate. An ignorant observer might have thought he outranked Birgitte. The falls of snow-white lace at his throat and wrists were twice as thick and twice as long as those worn by any of the Guardswomen, but he had left off the sash again, perhaps because it would have obscured one set of golden knots. He claimed that he wanted nothing more in life than to command her bodyguard, yet he frequently talked of battles he had fought as a mercenary. It seemed he had never been on the losing side, and victory had often come from his unsung efforts on the field. He swept off his white-plumed hat in a deep, flourishing bow, managing his sword deftly with one hand, then offered a slightly lesser to Birgitte with an arm across his chest in salute. Elayne arranged a smile on her face. "Sareitha says you were a hero again, Captain Mellar. How so?"

"nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən maɪ duɾi tə maɪ kwin." dɪspaɪɾ ə vɔɪs θɪk wɪð sɛlf-dɪpɹəkeɪʃən, hɪz ænsɝɪŋ smaɪl wɑz wɔɹmɝ ðən ɪt ʃəɾ əv bɪn. hæf ðə pæləs θɔɾ ɪm ðə fɑðɝ ʌv ɪleɪnz tʃaɪld. ðət ʃi hæd nɑt kɹʌʃt ðət ɹumɝ sim tə meɪk ɪm bɪliv i hæd pɹɑspɛks. ðə smaɪl nɛvɝ ɹitʃt ɪz dɑɹk aɪz, ðoʊ. ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn əz koʊld əz dɛθ. "maɪ duɾi tə jə ɪz maɪ plɛʒɝ, maɪ kwin."

"Nothing more than my duty to my queen." Despite a voice thick with self-deprecation, his answering smile was warmer than it should have been. Half the palace thought him the father of Elayne's child. That she had not crushed that rumor seemed to make him believe he had prospects. The smile never reached his dark eyes, though. They remained as cold as death. "My duty to you is my pleasure, my Queen."

"kæptən mɛlɝ lɛɾ ənʌðɝ sɔɹɾi wɪθaʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz jɛstɝdeɪ," bɝdʒɪt sɛɾ ɪn ə kɛɹfəli ivən vɔɪs. "ðɪs taɪm ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔlmoʊst spɪld ɪndə ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡeɪt, wɪtʃ i hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd lɛft oʊpən əɡɛnst ɪz ɹɪtɝn." ɪleɪn fɛlt əɹ feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɑɹd. "oʊ, noʊ," sɝaɪðə pɹətɛstəd. "ɪt wɑzn laɪk ðəɾ əɾ ɔl. ə hʌnʒɹəd ə lɔɹd lwɑnz ɑɹmmɪn tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi ɪn ðə naɪt, bʌt ðeɪ lɛft ɪt tu leɪt, ən sʌnɹaɪz kɑt ðɛm. soʊ dɪd θɹi taɪmz ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə lɔɹd næsənz mɛn. ɪf kæptən mɛlɝ hædn oʊpən ðə ɡeɪts ən lɛɾ ə ɹɛskju, ðeɪɾ əv bɪn kʌt tə pisəz ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə wɔlz. əz ɪt wɑz, hi mænədʒ tə seɪv eɪɾi fəɹ jəɹ kɑz." smaɪlɪŋ, mɛlɝ bæskt ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz pɹeɪz əz ɪf i hæd nɑt hɝd bɝdʒɪts kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. ʌv kɔɹs, hi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə kɛɝin ən mɛɝɪlɪlz dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ stɛɹz, tu. hi ɔlweɪz mænədʒ tə ɪɡnɔɹ dɪsəpɹuvəl.

"Captain Mellar led another sortie without orders yesterday," Birgitte said in a carefully even voice. "This time the righting almost spilled into the Far Madding Gate, which he had ordered left open against his return." Elayne felt her face growing hard. "Oh, no," Sareitha protested. "It wasn't like that at all. A hundred of Lord Luan's armsmen tried to reach the city in the night, but they left it too late, and sunrise caught them. So did three times their number of Lord Nasin's men. If Captain Mellar hadn't opened the gates and led a rescue, they'd have been cut to pieces in sight of the walls. As it was, he managed to save eighty for your cause." Smiling, Mellar basked in the Aes Sedai's praise as if he had not heard Birgitte's criticism. Of course, he seemed unaware of Careane and Merilille's disapproving stares, too. He always managed to ignore disapproval.

"haʊ dɪd jə noʊ ðeɪ wɝ lɔɹd lwɑnz mɛn, kæptən?" ɪleɪn æskt kwaɪətli. ə smɔl smaɪl ðət ʃʊɾə ɡɪvən mɛlɝ wɔɹnɪŋ əpɪɹɾ ɑn bɝdʒɪts feɪs. bʌt ðɛn, hi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u sim nɑt tə bɪliv ʃi wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ. ivən ɪf i dɪd, fju ɪksɛpt wɔɹɾɝz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ nu wʌt ðə bɑn ɪnteɪld. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, mɛlɝz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu mɔɹ smʌɡ. "aɪ dɪdnt ɡoʊ baɪ bænɝz, maɪ kwin.

"How did you know they were Lord Luan's men, Captain?" Elayne asked quietly. A small smile that should have given Mellar warning appeared on Birgitte's face. But then, he was one of those who seemed not to believe she was a Warder. Even if he did, few except Warders and Aes Sedai knew what the bond entailed. If anything, Mellar's expression grew more smug. "I didn't go by banners, my Queen.

ɛnibəɾi kən kæɹi ə bænɝ. aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz dʒʊɹæɾ ɑkən θɹu maɪ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. ɑkən ɪz lwɑnz mæn tə hɪz toʊneɪlz. wʌns aɪ nu ðæt. . . . " hi meɪɾ ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ ɪn ə flɝi ʌv leɪs. "ðə ɹɛst wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən teɪkɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɛksɝsaɪz."

Anybody can carry a banner. I recognized Jurad Accan through my looking glass. Accan is Luan's man to his toenails. Once I knew that. . . . " He made a dismissive gesture in a flurry of lace. "The rest was no more than taking a little exercise."

"æn dɪd ðɪs dʒʊɹæɾ ɑkən bɹɪŋ ɛni mɛsədʒ fɹəm lɔɹd lwɑn? ɛniθɪŋ saɪn ən sild, əfɝmɪŋ haʊs nɔɹwlɪnz səpɔɹt fəɹ tʃɹəkənd?"

"And did this Jurad Accan bring any message from Lord Luan? Anything signed and sealed, affirming House Norwelyn's support for Trakand?"

"nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ, maɪ kwin, bʌɾ əz aɪ sɛd - " "lɔɹd lwɑn əz nɑt dɪklɛɹd fəɹ mi, kæptən." mɛlɝz smaɪl feɪɾəd sʌmwʌt. hi wɑz ənjuz tə biɪŋ kʌt ʃɔɹt. "bʌt, maɪ kwin, leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn sɛz ðət lwɑn ɪz əz ɡʊɾ əz ɪn jəɹ kæmp ɹaɪt naʊ. ɑkən ʃoʊɪŋ ʌp ɪz pɹuf ʌv - "

"Nothing in writing, my Queen, but as I said - " "Lord Luan has not declared for me, Captain." Mellar's smile faded somewhat. He was unused to being cut short. "But, my Queen, Lady Dyelin says that Luan is as good as in your camp right now. Accan showing up is proof of - "

"ʌv nʌθɪŋ, kæptən," ɪleɪn sɛd koʊldli. "pɝhæps lɔɹd lwɑn wɪl bi ɪn maɪ kæmp ɪvɛntʃəwəli, kæptən, bʌɾ əntɪl i dɪklɛɹz, juv ɡɪvən mi eɪɾi mɛn u nid tə bi wɑtʃt." eɪɾi aʊɾ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd. ən haʊ mɛni ʌv hɝz hæɾ i lɔst? ən i hæd ɹɪskt keɪɛmlɪn duɪŋ ɪt, bɝn hɪm!
