"sɪns jə kən faɪn taɪm ɪn jəɹ duɾiz kəmændɪŋ maɪ bɑɾiɡɑɹd tə lid sɔɹɾiz, jə kən faɪn taɪm tə ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm. aɪ woʊn spɛɹ ɛniwʌn fɹəm ðə wɔlz fəɹ ɪt. sɛt mæstɝ ɑkən ən ɪz fɛloʊz tə dʒɹɪlɪŋ ðə mɛn aɪv bɹɔɾ ɪn fɹəm ðə mænɝz. ðət wɪl kip əm ɔl bɪzi ən aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl moʊst ʌv itʃ deɪ, bʌɾ aɪ liv ɪt tə jə haʊ tə kip əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔlz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taɪm. ən aɪ də ɪkspɛkt əm kɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɔlz ən aʊɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl, kæptən. jə meɪ si tə ɪt naʊ." mɛlɝ stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, stʌnd. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ teɪkən ɪm tə tæsk bɪfɔɹ, ən i dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪn fɹʌn ə soʊ mɛni wɪtnəsəz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ oʊvɝ-wɔɹm smaɪlz naʊ. hɪz maʊθ twɪtʃt, ən ə sʌlən hit ɡɹu ɪn ɪz aɪz. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə də ɪksɛp tə dʒɝk ənʌðɝ baʊ, mɝmɝ "æz maɪ kwin kəmænz" ɪn ə hɔɹs vɔɪs, ən liv wɪð əz ɡʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪs əz i kəd mʌstɝ. bɪfɔɹ i hæd ɡɔn θɹi peɪsɪz i wɑz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔl əz ɪf tə tʃɹæmpəl ɛniwʌn u ɡɑɾ ɪn ɪz weɪ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə tɛl ɹæsɔɹiə tə teɪk kɛɹ. hi maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə suð ɪz baɪl baɪ teɪkɪŋ ɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðoʊz u hæd sin ən hɝd. mɛɝɪlɪl ən kɛɝin ɡeɪv ɔlmoʊst aɪdɛntɪkəl nɑdz; ðeɪ wʊɾə sin mɛlɝ kɔl daʊn, ən pɹɛfɝəbli pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs, lɔŋ sɪns.

"Of nothing, Captain," Elayne said coldly. "Perhaps Lord Luan will be in my camp eventually, Captain, but until he declares, you've given me eighty men who need to be watched." Eighty out of a hundred. And how many of hers had he lost? And he had risked Caemlyn doing it, burn him! "Since you can find time in your duties commanding my bodyguard to lead sorties, you can find time to arrange for watching them. I won't spare anyone from the walls for it. Set Master Accan and his fellows to drilling the men I've brought in from the manors. That will keep them all busy and out of trouble most of each day, but I leave it to you how to keep them away from the walls the rest of the time. And I do expect them kept away from the walls and out of trouble, Captain. You may see to it now." Mellar stared at her, stunned. She had never taken him to task before, and he did not like it, particularly in front of so many witnesses. There were no over-warm smiles now. His mouth twitched, and a sullen heat grew in his eyes. But there was nothing for him to do except to jerk another bow, murmur "As my Queen commands" in a hoarse voice, and leave with as good a grace as he could muster. Before he had gone three paces he was striding down the hall as if to trample anyone who got in his way. She would have to tell Rasoria to take care. He might try to soothe his bile by taking it out on those who had seen and heard. Merilille and Careane gave almost identical nods; they would have seen Mellar called down, and preferably put out of the palace, long since.

"ivən ɪf i dɪd ɹɔŋ," sɝaɪðə sɛd kɛɹfəli, "æn aɪm nɑt kənvɪns ðəɾ i dɪd, kæptən mɛlɝ seɪv jəɹ laɪf ət ɹɪsk tə hɪz oʊn, ɪleɪn, jəɹ laɪf ən ðəɾ ə ðə leɪɾi daɪɛlɪn. wɑz ðəɹ ɹɪli nid tə ɪmbɛɹəs ɪm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs?" "nɛvɝ θɪŋk aɪ əvɔɪd peɪɪŋ maɪ dɛts, sɝaɪðə." ɪleɪn fɛlt eɪvinhə ɡɹɪp wʌn ə hɝ hænz, ən bɝdʒɪt ði ʌðɝ. ʃi ɡeɪv itʃ ə ðɛm ə laɪt skwiz. wən jə wɝ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɛnəmiz, ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hæv ə sɪstɝ ən ə fɹɛn kloʊs baɪ. "aɪ æm gɑnə faɪn ə hɑt bæθ naʊ, ən ənlɛs wʌn ə jə wɪʃɪz tə skɹʌb maɪ bæk . . . ?" ðeɪ kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə dɪsmɪsəl, ən ðeɪ dɪpɑɹɾəd mɔɹ ɡɹeɪsfəli ðən kæptən mɛlɝ, kɛɝin ən sɝaɪðə ɔlɹɛɾi dɪskʌsɪŋ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wəɾ æktʃəli  wɑn lɛsənz tədeɪ, mɛɝɪlɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns ɪn hoʊp ʌv əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɛni wɪndfɪndɝz. wʌt wəd ðeɪ tɔk ə leɪɾɝ, ðoʊ? wɛðɝ ɪleɪn wɑz hævɪŋ ə spæt wɪð ðə fɑðɝ ə hɝ tʃaɪld? wɛðɝ ðeɪ hæd səksɛsfəli hɪɾən ðɛɹ ɡɪlt ɪn kɪlɪŋ æɾɪliz?

"Even if he did wrong," Sareitha said carefully, "and I am not convinced that he did, Captain Mellar saved your life at risk to his own, Elayne, your life and that of the Lady Dyelin. Was there really need to embarrass him in front of the rest of us?" "Never think I avoid paying my debts, Sareitha." Elayne felt Aviendha grip one of her hands, and Birgitte the other. She gave each of them a light squeeze. When you were surrounded by enemies, it was good to have a sister and a friend close by. "I am going to find a hot bath now, and unless one of you wishes to scrub my back . . . ?" They could recognize a dismissal, and they departed more gracefully than Captain Mellar, Careane and Sareitha already discussing whether or not the Windfinders would actually want lessons today, Merilille trying to look every direction at once in hope of avoiding any Windfinders. What would they talk of later, though? Whether Elayne was having a spat with the father of her child? Whether they had successfully hidden their guilt in killing Adeleas?

aɪ ɔlweɪz peɪ maɪ dɛts, ɪleɪn θɔt, wɑtʃɪŋ əm ɡoʊ. ən aɪ hɛlp maɪ fɹɛnz peɪ ðɛɹz.

I always pay my debts, Elayne thought, watching them go. And I help my friends pay theirs.

tʃæptɝ twɛlv

CHAPTER 12

eɪ bɑɹɡən ə bæθ wɑz nɑt hɑɹd tə faɪnd, ðoʊ ɪleɪn hæd tə weɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔl fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz ə hɝ əpɑɹtməns, dʒɹæfs flɪkɝɪŋ ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps waɪl ɹæsɔɹiə ən tu ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɛn ɪn tə sɝtʃ. wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ əsæsənz laɪɪŋ ɪn weɪt, ən ɡɑɹdz hæd bɪn ɝeɪɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ən aʊɾɝ ɹum, ɪleɪn ɛntɝd tə faɪnd waɪt-hɛɹɾ ɛsænd weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɪð nænz ən sɛfæni, ðə tu jʌŋ taɪɹwɪmən ʃi wɑz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ɛsænd wɑz slɪm, wɪð ɪleɪnz ɡoʊldən lɪli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd oʊvɝ əɹ lɛf bɹɛst ən ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dɪɡnəɾi ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ hɝ dɪlɪbɝɪt weɪ ʌv muvɪŋ, ðoʊ səm ə ðət keɪm fɹəm eɪdʒ ən eɪkɪŋ dʒɔɪns ʃi ɹəfjuz tə æknɑlɪdʒ. nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni wɝ sɪstɝz, fɹɛʃ-feɪst, stɝɾi ən ʃaɪ-aɪd, pɹaʊɾ ə ðɛɹ lɪvɝi ən hæpi tə hæv bɪn tʃoʊzən aʊt fəɹ ðɪs ɹæðɝ ðən klinɪŋ hɔlweɪz bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ ɪn ɑ ʌv ɛsæn əz ʌv ɪleɪn. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns meɪdz əveɪləbəl, wɪmən u hæd wɝk jɪɹz ɪn ðə pæləs, bʌt sædli, ɡɝlz u hæd kʌm sikɪŋ ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv wɝk ðeɪ kəd faɪnd wɝ seɪfɝ.

A Bargain A bath was not hard to find, though Elayne had to wait in the hall frowning at the lion-carved doors of her apartments, drafts flickering the mirrored stand-lamps while Rasoria and two of the Guardswomen went in to search. Once they were sure there were no assassins lying in wait, and guards had been arrayed in the corridor and outer room, Elayne entered to find white-haired Essande waiting in the bedchamber with Nans and Sephanie, the two young tirewomen she was training. Essande was slim, with Elayne's Golden Lily embroidered over her left breast and a very great dignity emphasized by her deliberate way of moving, though some of that came from age and aching joints she refused to acknowledge. Naris and Sephanie were sisters, fresh-faced, sturdy and shy-eyed, proud of their livery and happy to have been chosen out for this rather than cleaning hallways but almost as much in awe of Essande as of Elayne. There were more experienced maids available, women who had worked years in the palace, but sadly, girls who had come seeking any sort of work they could find were safer.

tu kɑpɝ bæθtʌbz sæɾ ɑn θɪk leɪɝz ə taʊəlɪŋ leɪɾ ətɑp ðə ɹoʊz-kʌlɝd flɔɹ taɪlz wɛɹ wʌn ə ðə kɑɹpəts hæd bɪn ɹoʊld ʌp, ɛvəɾəns ðət wɝɾ ʌv ɪleɪnz ɝaɪvəl hæd floʊn əhɛɾ ə hɝ.

Two copper bathtubs sat on thick layers of toweling laid atop the rose-colored floor tiles where one of the carpets had been rolled up, evidence that word of Elayne's arrival had flown ahead of her.

sɝvəns hæɾ ə næk fəɹ lɝnɪŋ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ ðət ðə taʊɝz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz maɪɾ ɛnvi. ə ɡʊd bleɪz ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən taɪt keɪsməns ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz meɪd ðə ɹum wɔɹm æftɝ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz, ən ɛsænd weɪɾəd oʊnli tə si ɪleɪn ɛntɝ ðə ɹum bɪfɔɹ sɛndɪŋ sɛfæni ɔf əɾ ə ɹʌn tə fɛtʃ ðə mɛn wɪð ðə hɑt wɔɾɝ. ðət wəd bi bɹɔɾ ʌp ɪn dʌbəl-wɔl peɪlz wɪð lɪdz tə kip ɪt fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ koʊld ɑn ðə weɪ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz, ðoʊ ɪt maɪt bi dɪleɪɾ ə lɪɾəl baɪ ɡɑɹdzwɪmən tʃɛkɪŋ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ naɪvz hɪɾən ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ.

Servants had a knack for learning what was happening that the Tower's eyes-and-ears might envy. A good blaze in the fireplace and tight casements in the windows made the room warm after the corridors, and Essande waited only to see Elayne enter the room before sending Sephanie off at a run to fetch the men with the hot water. That would be brought up in double-walled pails with lids to keep it from getting cold on the way from the kitchens, though it might be delayed a little by Guardswomen checking to make sure there were no knives hidden in the water.

eɪvinhə aɪd ðə sɛkən bæθtəb ɔlmoʊst əz daʊtfəli əz ɛsæn aɪd bɝdʒɪt, ðə wʌn stɪl ənizi əbaʊɾ æktʃəli  stɛpɪŋ ɪndə wɔɾɝ ən ði ʌðɝ stɪl nɑɾ æksɛptɪŋ ðəɾ ɛniwʌn mɔɹ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi ʃəd bi pɹɛzən dʊɹɪŋ ə bæθ, bʌt ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən weɪstəd noʊ taɪm bɪfɔɹ kwaɪətli bʌsəlɪŋ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə boʊθ ɪndə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, wɛɹ ənʌðɝ faɪɝ ɑn ə waɪd mɑɹbəl hɑɹθ hæd teɪkən ðə tʃɪl fɹəm ði ɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlif tə hæv ɛsæn hɛlp əɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊðz, noʊɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd mɔɹ əhɛɾ ə hɝ ðən ə heɪsti wɑʃ ən ə ʃoʊ ʌv iz waɪl wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ kwɪkli ʃi kəd muv ɑn tə hɝ nɛks dɛstəneɪʃən. ʌðɝ pɹitɛnsɪz əweɪɾəd, ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ən ʌðɝ wɝiz, bʌt ʃi wɑz hoʊm, ən ðət kaʊntəd fəɹ mʌtʃ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ðət bikən ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə wɛst. ɔlmoʊst. wɛl, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl, ɹɪli, bʌt ʃi kəd mænədʒ tə stɑp fɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd nɑt dwɛl ɑn ðə θɪŋ.

Aviendha eyed the second bathtub almost as doubtfully as Essande eyed Birgitte, the one still uneasy about actually stepping into water and the other still not accepting that anyone more than necessary should be present during a bath, but the white-haired woman wasted no time before quietly bustling Elayne and Aviendha both into the dressing room, where another fire on a wide marble hearth had taken the chill from the air. It was a great relief to have Essande help her out of her riding clothes, knowing that she had more ahead of her than a hasty wash and a show of ease while worrying about how quickly she could move on to her next destination. Other pretenses awaited, the Light help her, and other worries, but she was home, and that counted for much. She could almost forget about that beacon shining in the west. Almost. Well, not at all, really, but she could manage to stop fretting over it as long as she did not dwell on the thing.

baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ hæd bɪn ənʒɹəst - wɪð eɪvinhə slæpɪŋ nɛɹɪs' hænz əweɪ ən ɹimuvɪŋ əɹ oʊn dʒuəlɹi, duɪŋ əɹ bɛs tə pɹitɛn ðət nɛɹɪs dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst ən əɹ ɡɑɹməns wɝ sʌmhaʊ ɹimuvɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz - baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ hæd bɪn bʌndəld ɪndə ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlk ɹoʊbz ən hæd ðɛɹ hɛɹ taɪɾ ʌp ɪn waɪt taʊəlɪŋ - eɪvinhə tʃɹaɪd tə ɹæp ðə taʊəl ɝaʊn əɹ oʊn hɛd θɹi taɪmz, ən oʊnli æftɝ ðə kənstʃɹʌkʃən kəlæps daʊn əɹ nɛk fəɹ ðə θɝd taɪm dɪd ʃi əlaʊ nɛɹɪs tə də ɪt, mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ soʊ sɑf ðət ʃi sun wəd nid sʌmwʌn tə leɪs ʌp əɹ buts əntɪl ɪleɪn bɪɡæn læfɪŋ ən ʃi dʒɔɪn ɪn, θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd bæk soʊ ðət nɛɹɪs hæd tə stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ əɡɛn - baɪ ðə taɪm ɔl ðət wɑz dʌn ən ðeɪ hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ðə bæθtʌbz wɝ fʊl ən ðə sɛn ə ðə ɹoʊz ɔɪl ðət hæd bɪn æɾəd tə ðə wɔɾɝ fɪl ði ɛɹ. ðə mɛn u hæd bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə wɔɾɝ wɝ ɡɔn, ʌv kɔɹs, ən sɛfæni wɑz weɪɾɪŋ wɪð əɹ slivz pʊʃt əbʌv əɹ ɛlboʊz ɪn keɪs sʌmwʌn wɑntəɾ əɹ bæk skɹʌbd. bɝdʒɪt wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə tɝkwɔɪz-ɪnleɪd tʃɛst ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛd, hɝ ɛlboʊz ɑn əɹ niz.

By the time they had been undressed - with Aviendha slapping Naris' hands away and removing her own jewelry, doing her best to pretend that Naris did not exist and her garments were somehow removing themselves - by the time they had been bundled into embroidered silk robes and had their hair tied up in white toweling - Aviendha tried to wrap the towel around her own head three times, and only after the construction collapsed down her neck for the third time did she allow Naris to do it, muttering about getting so soft that she soon would need someone to lace up her boots until Elayne began laughing and she joined in, throwing her head back so that Naris had to start over again - by the time all that was done and they had returned to the bedchamber, the bathtubs were full and the scent of the rose oil that had been added to the water filled the air. The men who had brought up the water were gone, of course, and Sephanie was waiting with her sleeves pushed above her elbows in case someone wanted her back scrubbed. Birgitte was sitting on the turquoise-inlaid chest at the foot of the bed, her elbows on her knees.

ɪleɪn əlaʊɾ ɛsæn tə hɛlp əɹ ɔf wɪð əɹ peɪl ɡɹin, swɑloʊ-wɝkt ɹoʊb ən sæŋk ɪndə hɝ tʌb ɪmiɾiətli, səbmɝdʒɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə hɝ nɛk ɪn wɔɾɝ dʒʌst ə hɛɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə tu hɑt. ðət lɛft əɹ niz poʊkɪŋ ʌp, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɪmɝs moʊst ə hɝ ɪn ðə wɔɹmθ, ən ʃi saɪd, filɪŋ wɪɹinəs litʃ aʊɾ ə hɝ ən læŋɝ kɹip ɪn. hɑt wɔɾɝ maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɪŋɡəl ɡɪft ə sɪvəlɪzeɪʃən.

Elayne allowed Essande to help her off with her pale green, swallow-worked robe and sank into her tub immediately, submerging herself to her neck in water just a hair short of too hot. That left her knees poking up, but it immersed most of her in the warmth, and she sighed, feeling weariness leach out of her and languor creep in. Hot water might have been the greatest single gift of civilization.

stɛɹɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ tʌb, eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən nɛɹɪs ətɛmptəd tə ɹimuv əɹ ɹoʊb, lævəndɝ ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð flaʊɝz ɑn ðə waɪd slivz. ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, ʃi faɪnəli əlaʊɾ ɪt, ən stɛp dʒɪnʒɝli ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝ, bʌt ʃi snætʃt ðə ɹaʊn soʊp aʊɾ ə sɛfæniz hæn ən bɪɡæn wɑʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf vɪɡɝəsli. vɪɡɝəsli, bʌt vɛɹi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə slɑp soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə spunfʊl ʌv wɔɾɝ oʊvɝ ðə tʌbz ɹɪm. ði il dɪd juz wɔɾɝ fəɹ wɑʃɪŋ, əz wɛl əz ɪn ðə swɛt tɛns, ɪspɛʃli fəɹ ɹɪnsɪŋ aʊt ðə ʃæmpu ðeɪ meɪd fɹəm ə fæt lif ðət ɡɹu ɪn ðə weɪst, jɛt ðə dɝɾi wɔɾɝ wɑz kənsɝvd ən juz fəɹ wɔɾɝɪŋ kɹɑps. ɪleɪn hæd ʃoʊn əɹ tu ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪstɝnz bɪniθ keɪɛmlɪn, fɛd baɪ ə pɛɹ ʌv ʌndɝɡɹaʊn ɹɪvɝz ən lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf ðət ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ʌv itʃ wɑz lɔst ɪn ə fɔɹəst ə θɪk kɑləmz ən ʃædoʊz, bʌt ði æɹəd weɪst wɑz ɪn eɪvinhəz boʊnz.

Staring at the other tub, Aviendha gave a start when Naris attempted to remove her robe, lavender and embroidered with flowers on the wide sleeves. Grimacing, she finally allowed it, and stepped gingerly into the water, but she snatched the round soap out of Sephanie's hand and began washing herself vigorously. Vigorously, but very careful not to slop so much as a spoonful of water over the tub's rim. The Aiel did use water for washing, as well as in the sweat tents, especially for rinsing out the shampoo they made from a fat leaf that grew in the Waste, yet the dirty water was conserved and used for watering crops. Elayne had shown her two of the great cisterns beneath Caemlyn, fed by a pair of underground rivers and large enough that the far side of each was lost in a forest of thick columns and shadows, but the arid Waste was in Aviendha's bones.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛsænz pɔɪntəd lʊks -  ʃi sɛldəm sɛd tu wɝdz mɔɹ ðən nɛsəsɛɹi, ən θɔt bæθz noʊ taɪm tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ - bɝdʒɪt tɔkt waɪl ðeɪ beɪðd, ðoʊ ʃi tʊk kɛɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi sɛɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə peɪ ʌv ənʌðɝ haʊs, bʌt meɪdz ɡɑsaɪpt ɔlmoʊst əz fɹili əz mɛn - ɪt simd ɔlmoʊst ə tʃɹədɪʃən. səm ɹumɝz wɝ wɝθ fɑstɝɪŋ, nʌnðəlɛs. moʊsli bɝdʒɪt tɔkt ə tu hjudʒ mɝtʃəns' tʃɹeɪnz ðət hæɾ ɝaɪv jɛstɝdeɪ fɹəm tɛɹ, ðə wæɡənz hɛvi wɪð ɡɹeɪn ən sɔltəd bif, ən ənʌðɝ fɹəm ɪljən wɪð ɔɪl ən sɔlt ən smoʊk fɪʃ.

Ignoring Essande's pointed looks -  she seldom said two words more than necessary, and thought baths no time to say anything - Birgitte talked while they bathed, though she took care of what she said in front of Naris and Sephanie. It was unlikely they were in the pay of another House, but maids gossiped almost as freely as men - it seemed almost a tradition. Some rumors were worth fostering, nonetheless. Mostly Birgitte talked of two huge merchants' trains that had arrived yesterday from Tear, the wagons heavy with grain and salted beef, and another from Illian with oil and salt and smoked fish.

ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz wɝθwaɪl ɹimaɪndɪŋ pipəl ðət fud kəntɪnjud tə floʊ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. fju mɝtʃəns bɹeɪv ðə ɹoʊdz ʌv ændɝ ɪn wɪntɝ, nʌn kæɹiɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əz tʃip əz fud, bʌt ɡeɪtweɪz mɛn ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə kəɾ ɪntɝsɛpt ɔl ðə mɝtʃəns ʃi wɪʃt ən əɹ fɔɹsɪz stɪl wəd stɑɹv lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ keɪɛmlɪn fɛl ðə fɝs pæŋz ə hʌŋɡɝ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, hu wɝ meɪkɪŋ moʊst ə ðoʊz ɡeɪtweɪz, ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn - kleɪmɪŋ ðə taɪɾəl ə stuɝɾ ɪn tiɹ fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz! - wɑz bɪsidʒd ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ baɪ noʊbəlz u wɑntəd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn aʊɾ ə tɛɹ kəmplitli, bʌɾ ivən ðeɪ wɝ ənlaɪkli tə tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ ə ɹɪtʃ tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ɡɹeɪn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sɪns ðeɪ bɪliv ðə kɪn u əkʌmpənid ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑt ðəɾ ɛni ɹil ətɛmpt wɑz meɪɾ ət dɪsɛpʃən, bʌt ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋz hæd bɪn meɪd fəɹ kɪnswɪmən u hæd pæs ðɛɹ tɛsts fəɹ æksɛptɪd bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, ən ɪf ɛniwʌn dʒɹu ðə ɹɔŋ kənkluʒən, noʊ wʌn æktʃəli  laɪd tə ðɛm. ðə wɔɾɝ gɑnə tə ʃɛɾ ɪts hiɾ ɪf ʃi weɪɾəd mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ɪleɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd, soʊ ʃi tʊk ə ɹoʊz-sɛntɪd soʊp fɹəm sɛfæni ən əlaʊd nɛɹɪs tə bɪɡɪn skɹʌbɪŋ əɹ bæk wɪð ə lɔŋ-hændəl bɹʌʃ. ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn nuz ʌv ɡɔɪn əɹ ɡɑləd, wʊɾə əv mɛnʃən ɪt stʃɹeɪɾ ɔf.

It was always worthwhile reminding people that food continued to flow into the city. Few merchants braved the roads of Andor in winter, none carrying anything as cheap as food, but gateways meant that Arymilla could intercept all the merchants she wished and her forces still would starve long before Caemlyn felt the first pangs of hunger. The Windfinders, who were making most of those gateways, reported that the High Lord Darlin - claiming the title of Steward in Tear for the Dragon Reborn, of all things! - was besieged in the Stone of Tear by nobles who wanted the Dragon Reborn out of Tear completely, but even they were unlikely to try stopping a rich trade in grain, particularly since they believed the Kin who accompanied the Windfinders were Aes Sedai. Not that any real attempt was made at deception, but Great Serpent rings had been made for Kinswomen who had passed their tests for Accepted before being put out of the Tower, and if anyone drew the wrong conclusion, no one actually lied to them. The water was going to shed its heat if she waited much longer, Elayne decided, so she took a rose-scented soap from Sephanie and allowed Naris to begin scrubbing her back with a long-handled brush. If there had been news of Gawyn or Galad, Birgitte would have mentioned it straight off.

ʃi wɑz əz iɡɝ tə hɪɹ əz ɪleɪn, ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv hɛld ɪt bæk. ɡɔɪnz ɹɪtɝn wɑz wʌn ɹumɝ ðeɪ dɪɹli wɑntəd tə ɹitʃ ðə stʃɹits. bɝdʒɪt pɝfɔɹmd əɹ duɾiz wɛl əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, ən ɪleɪn mɛn əɹ tə kip ðə pəzɪʃən, ɪf ʃi kəd bi kənvɪnst, bʌt hævɪŋ ɡɔɪn ðəɹ wəɾ əlaʊ boʊθ wɪmən tə ɹɪlæks ə lɪɾəl. moʊst ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɝ mɝsənɛɹiz, ən oʊnli ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə mæn ðə ɡeɪts stʃɹɔŋli ən meɪk ə dɪspleɪ əlɔŋ ðə maɪlz ʌv wɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə nu sɪɾi, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl nʌmbɝd mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi kʌmpəniz, itʃ wɪð ɪts oʊn kæptən u ɪnɛvəɾəbli wɑz fʊl ə pɹaɪd, əbsɛst wɪð pɹɛsəɾəns, ən ɹɛɾi tə skwɑbəl oʊvɝ ɛni ɪmædʒən slaɪt fɹəm ənʌðɝ kæptən ət ðə dʒɹɑp ʌv ə stʃɹɔ. ɡɔɪn hæd tʃɹeɪn ɪz hoʊl laɪf tə kəmæn ɑɹmiz. hi kəd dil wɪð ðə skwɑblɝz, livɪŋ əɹ fɹi tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə θɹoʊn. əpɑɹt fɹəm ðæt, ʃi sɪmpli wɑntəɾ ɪm əweɪ fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ʃi pɹeɪd ðət wʌn ə hɝ mɛsənʒɝz hæd ɡɑɾən θɹu ən ðəɾ i wɑz wɛl daʊnɹɪvɝ baɪ ðɪs taɪm. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn bɪsidʒɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð əɹ ɑɹmi fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə wik, naʊ, ən ɪt wəd bi ðə kɹuləst spɪnɪŋ ə feɪt fəɹ ɡɔɪn tə bi kɑt bɪtwin ɪz oʊðz tə dɪfɛn ðə taʊɝ ən ɪz lʌv fəɹ ɛɡwin.

She was as eager to hear as Elayne, and she could not have held it back. Gawyn's return was one rumor they dearly wanted to reach the streets. Birgitte performed her duties well as Captain-General, and Elayne meant her to keep the position, if she could be convinced, but having Gawyn there would allow both women to relax a little. Most of the soldiers in the city were mercenaries, and only enough of them to man the gates strongly and make a display along the miles of wall surrounding the New City, but they still numbered more than thirty companies, each with its own captain who inevitably was full of pride, obsessed with precedence, and ready to squabble over any imagined slight from another captain at the drop of a straw. Gawyn had trained his whole life to command armies. He could deal with the squabblers, leaving her free to secure the throne. Apart from that, she simply wanted him away from the White Tower. She prayed that one of her messengers had gotten through and that he was well downriver by this time. Egwene had been besieging Tar Valon with her army for more than a week, now, and it would be the cruelest spinning of fate for Gawyn to be caught between his oaths to defend the Tower and his love for Egwene.

wɝs, hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɹoʊkən ðəɾ oʊθ wʌns, əɹ ət lis bɛn ɪt, fəɹ lʌv ə hɪz sɪstɝ ən pɝhæps ɪz lʌv ʌv ɛɡwin. ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɛvɝ səspɛktəd ðət ɡɔɪn hæɾ eɪɾəd sɪuənz ɪskeɪp, wʌtɛvɝ kɹɛɾət i hæd ɡeɪn baɪ hɛlpɪŋ əɹ ɹipleɪs sɪuən əz æmɪɝlɪn wəɾ ɪvæpɝeɪt laɪk ə dudʒɹɑp, ən ɪf i wɑz stɪl wɪðɪn ɪleɪɾəz ɹitʃ wən ʃi lɝnd, hi wəd faɪn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə sɛl, ən lʌki tə əvɔɪd ðə hɛdzmən. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɪzɛn ɪz dɪsɪʒən tə eɪɾ ɪleɪɾə; hi kəd nɑɾ əv noʊn ɪnʌf ðən tə meɪk ɛni ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs. ə ɡʊd mɛni sɪstɝz hæd bɪn kənfjuzd oʊvɝ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, tu. ə ɡʊd mɛni stɪl sim tə bi. haʊ kəd ʃi æsk ɡɔɪn tə si wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt?

Worse, he had already broken that oath once, or at least bent it, for love of his sister and perhaps his love of Egwene. If Elaida ever suspected that Gawyn had aided Siuan's escape, whatever credit he had gained by helping her replace Siuan as Amyrlin would evaporate like a dewdrop, and if he was still within Elaida's reach when she learned, he would find himself in a cell, and lucky to avoid the headsman. Elayne did not resent his decision to aid Elaida; he could not have known enough then to make any other choice. A good many sisters had been confused over what was happening, too. A good many still seemed to be. How could she ask Gawyn to see what Aes Sedai could not?

əz fəɹ ɡɑləd. . . . ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp əneɪbəl tə laɪk ðə mæn, ʃʊɹ i mʌst ɹɪzɛn hɝ, ən ɹɪzɛnt ɡɔɪn moʊst ʌv ɔl. ɡɑləd hæd tə hæv θɔɾ i wəd bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wʌn deɪ, əntɪl ɡɔɪn wɑz bɔɹn. hɝ ɝliəs mɛmɹiz ə hɪm wɝ ʌv ə bɔɪ, ə jʌŋ mæn, ɔlɹɛɾi bɪheɪvɪŋ mɔɹ laɪk ə fɑðɝ əɹ ʌŋkəl ðən ə bɹʌðɝ, ɡɪvɪŋ ɡɔɪn ɪz fɝs lɛsənz wɪð ə sɔɹd. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ i wəd bɹeɪk oʊpən ɡɔɪnz hɛd wɪð ðə pɹæktəs bleɪd. bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɡɪvən mɔɹ ðən ðə bɹuzəz ɛni juθ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn lɝnɪŋ sɔɹdz. hi nu wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt, ɡɑləd dɪd, ən i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə də wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt noʊ mæɾɝ ðə kɑs tə ɛniwʌn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. laɪt, hi hæd stɑɹɾəd ə wɔɹ tə hɛlp əɹ ən nɪneɪiv ɪskeɪp fɹəm sæmɝə, ən ɪt wɑz laɪkli hi hæd noʊn ðə ɹɪsk fɹəm ðə stɑɹt! ɡɑləd fænsid nɪneɪiv, əɹ hæd fəɹ ə taɪm - ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə ɪmædʒən i stɪl fɛl ðət weɪ, wɪð ɪm ə waɪtkloʊk, ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wɛɹ ən duɪŋ wʌt - bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ wɑz, hi hæd stɑɹɾəd ðət wɔɹ tə ɹɛskju hɪz sɪstɝ. ʃi kəd nɑt kəndoʊn ɪm biɪŋ ə tʃaɪld ə ðə laɪt, ʃi kəd nɑt laɪk hɪm, jɛt ʃi hoʊp ðəɾ i wɑz seɪf ən wɛl. ʃi hoʊpt i faʊn ɪz weɪ hoʊm tə keɪɛmlɪn, tu. nuz ə hɪm wʊɾə bɪn nɪɹli əz wɛlkəm əz nuz ʌv ɡɔɪn. ðət sɝpɹaɪz hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. "tu mɔɹ sɪstɝz keɪm waɪl jə wɝ əweɪ. ðəɹ ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn." bɝdʒɪt meɪɾ ɪt saʊn əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ mɪɹli stɑpɪŋ əɾ ən ɪn kəz ɛvɹi bɛɾ ɪn ðə pæləs wɑz teɪkən. "eɪ ɡɹin wɪð tu wɔɹɾɝz ən ə ɡɹeɪ wɪð wʌn. ðeɪ keɪm sɛpɝətli. eɪ jɛloʊ ən ə bɹaʊn lɛf ðə seɪm deɪ, soʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl tɛn ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ðə jɛloʊ wɛn saʊθ, təwɔɹd fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ðə bɹaʊn wɑz hɛɾɪŋ ist." sɛfæni, weɪɾɪŋ peɪʃənli bɪsaɪɾ eɪvinhəz tʌb wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə du, ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə ɡlæns wɪð əɹ sɪstɝ oʊvɝ ɪleɪnz hɛɾ ən ɡɹɪnd. laɪk mɛni ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ðeɪ nu fəɹ ə fæk ðət ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn sɪɡnəfaɪd waɪt taʊɝ səpɔɹt fəɹ ɪleɪn ən haʊs tʃɹəkənd.

As for Galad. . . . She had grown up unable to like the man, sure he must resent her, and resent Gawyn most of all. Galad had to have thought he would be First Prince of the Sword one day, until Gawyn was born. Her earliest memories of him were of a boy, a young man, already behaving more like a father or uncle than a brother, giving Gawyn his first lessons with a sword. She remembered being afraid he would break open Gawyn's head with the practice blade. But he had never given more than the bruises any youth expected in learning swords. He knew what was right, Galad did, and he was willing to do what was right no matter the cost to anyone, including himself. Light, he had started a war to help her and Nynaeve escape from Samara, and it was likely he had known the risk from the start! Galad fancied Nynaeve, or had for a time - it was hard to imagine he still felt that way, with him a Whitecloak, the Light only knew where and doing what - but the truth was, he had started that war to rescue his sister. She could not condone him being a Child of the Light, she could not like him, yet she hoped that he was safe and well. She hoped he found his way home to Caemlyn, too. News of him would have been nearly as welcome as news of Gawyn. That surprised her, but it was true. "Two more sisters came while you were away. They're at the Silver Swan." Birgitte made it sound as though they were merely stopping at an inn because every bed in the palace was taken. "A Green with two Warders and a Gray with one. They came separately. A Yellow and a Brown left the same day, so there are still ten altogether. The Yellow went south, toward Far Madding. The Brown was heading east." Sephanie, waiting patiently beside Aviendha's tub with nothing to do, exchanged a glance with her sister over Elayne's head and grinned. Like many in the city, they knew for a fact that the presence of Aes Sedai at the Silver Swan signified White Tower support for Elayne and House Trakand.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tu ɡɝlz laɪk ə hɔk, ɛsænd nɑɾəd; ʃi nu ɪt, tu. ɛvɹi stʃɹitswipɝ ən ɹæɡpɪkɝ wɑz əwɛɹ ðət ðə taʊɝ wɑz dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf, bʌɾ ivən soʊ, ðə neɪm stɪl kæɹid weɪt, ən ən ɪmədʒ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ðət nɛvɝ feɪld. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd lɛn səpɔɹt tə ɛvɹi ɹaɪtfəl kwin ʌv ændɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, moʊst sɪstɝz lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ə sɪɾɪŋ mɑnɑɹk u wɑz ɔlsoʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə fɝst ɪn ə θaʊzən jɪɹz ən ðə fɝst sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝl tə bi oʊpənli noʊn əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wəd nɑt bi sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðəɹ wɑz ə sɪstɝ ɪn ɛɹəmɪləz kæmp, kipɪŋ dɪskɹitli aʊɾ ə noʊɾəs. ðə waɪt taʊɝ nɛvɝ pleɪst ɔl ʌv ɪts kɔɪn ɑn wʌn hɔɹs ənlɛs ðə ɹeɪs wɑz fɪkst.

Watching the two girls like a hawk, Essande nodded; she knew it, too. Every streetsweeper and ragpicker was aware that the Tower was divided against itself, but even so, the name still carried weight, and an image of strength that never failed. Everyone knew the White Tower had lent support to every rightful Queen of Andor. In truth, most sisters looked forward to a sitting monarch who was also Aes Sedai, the first in a thousand years and the first since the Breaking of the World to be openly known as Aes Sedai, but Elayne would not be surprised to find there was a sister in Arymilla's camp, keeping discreetly out of notice. The White Tower never placed all of its coin on one horse unless the race was fixed.

"ðæts ɪnʌf ə ðə bɹʌʃ," ʃi sɛd, ɪɹɪɾəbli twɪstɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɹɪsəlz. wɛl tʃɹeɪnd, ðə ɡɝl leɪd ðə bɹʌʃ daʊn ɑn ə stul ən hændəɾ əɹ ə lɑɹdʒ ɪliɑnɝ spʌnʒ ðət ʃi juz tə bɪɡɪn slusɪŋ ɔf soʊp. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi nu wʌt ðoʊz sɪstɝz mɛnt. ðeɪ wɝ laɪk ə ɡɹeɪn ə sæn ɪn əɹ slɪpɝ, soʊ taɪni ə θɪŋ ðət jə kəd hɑɹdli ɪmædʒən ɪt biɪŋ ə dɪskʌmfɝt, bʌt ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪt ɹɪmeɪnd, ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ɪt simd. ðə sɪstɝz ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ ə saɪzəbəl stoʊn dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ ðɛɹ.

"That's enough of the brush," she said, irritably twisting away from the bristles. Well trained, the girl laid the brush down on a stool and handed her a large Illianer sponge that she used to begin sluicing off soap. She wished she knew what those sisters meant. They were like a grain of sand in her slipper, so tiny a thing that you could hardly imagine it being a discomfort, but the longer it remained, the larger it seemed. The sisters at the Silver Swan were becoming a sizable stone just by being there.

sɪns bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɝaɪvd ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ðə nʌmbɝ ət ði ɪn hæd bɪn tʃeɪnʒd fɹikwənli, ə fju sɪstɝz livɪŋ ɛvɹi wik ən ə fju kʌmɪŋ tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm. ðə sidʒ hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ɛniθɪŋ; ðə soʊlʒɝz sɝaʊndɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn wɝ noʊ mɔɹ laɪkli tə tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ wɛɹ ʃi wɑntəd ðən wɝ ðə ɹɪbɛljəs noʊbəlz ɪn tɛɹ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɹɛdz ɪn ðə sɪɾi tu, fəɹ ə waɪl, æskɪŋ æftɝ mɛn hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə blæk taʊɝ, bʌt ðə mɔɹ ðeɪ lɝnd, ðə mɔɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛt ðɛɹ dɪsɡɹʌntəlmənt ʃoʊ, ən ðə læs pɛɹ hæd ɹɪɾən aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ðə deɪ æftɝ ɛɹəmɪlə əpɪɹd bɪfɔɹ ðə wɔlz. ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi wɑz kɛɹfəli wɑtʃt, ən nʌn ə ðə ɹɛdz hæd ɡɔn nɪɹ ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn, soʊ ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðə sɪstɝz ðəɹ hæd bɪn sɛn baɪ ɪleɪɾə tə kɪdnæp hɝ. fəɹ səm ɹizən ʃi ɪmædʒən lɪɾəl ɡɹups ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ skæɾɝd fɹəm ðə blaɪt tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ən kɑnstən stʃɹimz ə sɪstɝz floʊɪŋ bɪtwin, ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ʃɛɹɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ə pəkjuljɝ θɔt. sɪstɝz juzd aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz tə wɑtʃ ðə wɝld, ən ɹɛɹli ʃɛɹd wʌt ðeɪ lɝn ənlɛs ɪt wɑz ə θɹɛt tə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. laɪkli ðoʊz ət ðə swɑn wɝ əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz sɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðə taʊɝz tʃɹʌbəlz, weɪɾɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ ɛɡwin əɹ ɪleɪɾə wəɾ ɛnd wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪklɛɹd ðɛmsɛlvz. ðət wɑz ɹɔŋ - ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃəd stæn fəɹ wʌt ʃi θɔt wɑz ɹaɪt wɪθaʊt wɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz tʃuzɪŋ ðə wɪnɪŋ saɪd! - bʌt ðiz meɪɾ əɹ ənizi fəɹ ənʌðɝ ɹizən.

Since before she arrived in Caemlyn the number at the inn had been changed frequently, a few sisters leaving every week and a few coming to replace them. The siege had not changed anything; the soldiers surrounding Caemlyn were no more likely to try stopping an Aes Sedai from going where she wanted than were the rebellious nobles in Tear. There had been Reds in the city too, for a while, asking after men heading for the Black Tower, but the more they learned, the more they had let their disgruntlement show, and the last pair had ridden out of the city the day after Arymilla appeared before the walls. Every Aes Sedai who entered the city was carefully watched, and none of the Reds had gone near the Silver Swan, so it seemed unlikely the sisters there had been sent by Elaida to kidnap her. For some reason she imagined little groups of Aes Sedai scattered from the Blight to the Sea of Storms, and constant streams of sisters flowing between, gathering information, sharing information. A peculiar thought. Sisters used eyes-and-ears to watch the world, and rarely shared what they learned unless it was a threat to the Tower itself. Likely those at the Swan were among the sisters sitting out the Tower's troubles, waiting to see whether Egwene or Elaida would end with the Amyrlin Seat before they declared themselves. That was wrong - an Aes Sedai should stand for what she thought was right without worrying over whether she was choosing the winning side! - but these made her uneasy for another reason.

ɹisənli wʌn ə hɝ wɑtʃɝz ət ðə swɑn hæɾ oʊvɝhɝɾ ə dɪstɝbɪŋ neɪm, mɝmɝɾ ən kwɪkli ʃʌʃt, əz ɪf ɪn fɪɹ ʌv ivzdʒɹɑpɝz. kædzueɪn. nɑɾ ə kɑmən neɪm, ðæt. ən kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn hæd mɛʃt hɝsɛlf kloʊsli wɪð ɹænd waɪl i wɑz ɪn kɛɹhin. vændin dɪd nɑt θɪŋk mʌtʃ ə ðə wʊmən, kɔlɪŋ əɹ əpɪnjəneɪɾɪd ən mjulhɛɾɪd, bʌt kɛɝin hæɾ ɔlmoʊs feɪntɪɾ ɪn ɑ ət hɪɹɪŋ əɹ neɪm. ɪt sim ðə stɔɹiz sɝaʊndɪŋ kædzueɪn əmaʊntɪd tə lɛdʒənz. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dil wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn sɪŋɡəl-hændəd wɑz dʒʌs ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn maɪt du. nɑt ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd kənsɝnz əbaʊt ɹænd ən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i maɪɾ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ əɹ bɪɑn əɹ kəntʃɹoʊl - ðə mæn wɑz tu paɪɡhɛɾɪd hɪmsɛlf səmtaɪmz tə si wɛɹ ɪz oʊn ɡʊd leɪ! - bʌt waɪ wəɾ ə sɪstɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn mɛnʃən əɹ neɪm? ən waɪ hæɾ ənʌðɝ hʌʃt hɝ? dɪspaɪt ðə hɑt bæθwɔɾɝ, ʃi ʃɪvɝd, θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɔl ðə wɛbz ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd spʌn θɹu ðə sɛntʃɝiz, soʊ faɪn ðət nʌn kəd si ðɛm ɪksɛp ðə sɪstɝz u dɪd ðə spɪnɪŋ, soʊ kɑnvəluɾəd ðət nʌn bʌt ðoʊz sɪstɝz cʊɾə ənɹævəl ðɛm. ðə taʊɝ spʌn wɛbz, ði ədʒəz spʌn wɛbz, ivən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl sɪstɝz spʌn wɛbz. səmtaɪmz ðoʊz skimz blɛndəɾ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ðoʊ ɡaɪɾəd baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl hænd. ʌðɝ taɪmz ðeɪ hæd pʊld wʌn ənʌðɝ əpɑɹt. ðət wɑz haʊ ðə wɝl hæd bɪn ʃeɪp fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz. naʊ ðə taʊɝ hæd dɪvaɪɾəd ɪtsɛlf nitli ɪndə ɹʌf θɝdz, wʌn θɝd fəɹ ɛɡwin, wʌn fəɹ ɪleɪɾə, ən wʌn ðət wɑz stændɪŋ əsaɪd. ɪf ðoʊz læst wɝ ɪn kɑntækt wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən - fɔɹmɪŋ plænz? - ði ɪmpləkeɪʃənz. . . . ə sʌɾən tuməlt ə vɔɪsəz, dɪm baɪ ðə kloʊz dɔɹ, meɪɾ əɹ sɪɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni skwild ən lɛp tə klʌtʃ wʌn ənʌðɝ, stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ət ðə dɔɹ.

Recently one of her watchers at the Swan had overheard a disturbing name, murmured and quickly shushed, as if in fear of eavesdroppers. Cadsuane. Not a common name, that. And Cadsuane Melaidhrin had meshed herself closely with Rand while he was in Cairhien. Vandene did not think much of the woman, calling her opinionated and muleheaded, but Careane had almost fainted in awe at hearing her name. It seemed the stories surrounding Cadsuane amounted to legends. Trying to deal with the Dragon Reborn single-handed was just the sort of thing Cadsuane Melaidhrin might do. Not that Elayne had concerns about Rand and any Aes Sedai, except that he might outrage her beyond her control - the man was too pigheaded himself sometimes to see where his own good lay! - but why would a sister in Caemlyn mention her name? And why had another hushed her? Despite the hot bathwater, she shivered, thinking of all the webs the White Tower had spun through the centuries, so fine that none could see them except the sisters who did the spinning, so convoluted that none but those sisters could have unraveled them. The Tower spun webs, the Ajahs spun webs, even individual sisters spun webs. Sometimes those schemes blended into one another as though guided by a single hand. Other times they had pulled one another apart. That was how the world had been shaped for three thousand years. Now the Tower had divided itself neatly into rough thirds, one third for Egwene, one for Elaida, and one that was standing aside. If those last were in contact with one another, exchanging information - forming plans? - the implications. . . . A sudden tumult of voices, dimmed by the closed door, made her sit up straight. Naris and Sephanie squealed and leaped to clutch one another, staring wide-eyed at the door.

"wʌɾ ɪn ðə blʌɾi fleɪmɪŋ . . . ?" snɑɹlɪŋ, bɝdʒɪt hɝl hɝsɛlf ɔf ðə tʃɛst ən aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, slæmɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz haɪɝ.

"What in the bloody flaming . . . ?" Snarling, Birgitte hurled herself off the chest and out of the room, slamming the door behind her. The voices rose higher.

ɪt dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɝ faɪɾɪŋ, dʒʌst ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ət ðə tɑps ə ðə lʌŋz, ən ðə bɑn kæɹid meɪnli æŋɡɝ ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ blʌɾi hɛdeɪk, bʌɾ ɪleɪn klaɪmd aʊɾ ə ðə bæθtəb, hoʊldɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ ɑɹmz fəɹ ɛsæn tə slɪp əɹ ɹoʊb ɑn. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmənz kɑmnəs, ən pɝhæps ɪleɪnz, suðd ðə tu meɪdz ɪnʌf ðət ðeɪ blʌʃt wən ɛsæn lʊkt ət ðɛm, bʌɾ eɪvinhə lɛp fɹəm əɹ tʌb, splæʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən dæʃt dʒɹɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum. ɪleɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə ɹɪtɝn wɪð əɹ bɛl naɪf, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ʃi keɪm bæk sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊ oʊɪseɪaɪdɑɹ ən hoʊldɪŋ ði æmbɝ tɝɾəl ɪn wʌn hænd. wɪð ði ʌðɝ ʃi hændəɾ ɪleɪn ði æŋɡɹil ðət hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ən eɪdʒɪɾ aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə wʊmən kloʊðd oʊnli ɪn əɹ hɛɹ.

It did not sound as if the Guardswomen were fighting, just arguing at the tops of the lungs, and the bond carried mainly anger and frustration, along with her bloody headache, but Elayne climbed out of the bathtub, holding out her arms for Essande to slip her robe on. The white-haired woman's calmness, and perhaps Elayne's, soothed the two maids enough that they blushed when Essande looked at them, but Aviendha leaped from her tub, splashing water everywhere, and dashed dripping into the dressing room. Elayne expected her to return with her belt knife, but instead she came back surrounded by the glow oisaidar and holding the amber turtle in one hand. With the other she handed Elayne the angreal that had been in her belt pouch, an aged ivory carving of a woman clothed only in her hair.

ɛksɛptɪŋ ðə taʊəl ətɑp əɹ hɛd, eɪvinhə wɔɹ oʊnli ə wɛt ʃin, ən ʃi æŋɡɹəli weɪv sɛfæni əweɪ wən ðə wʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ əɹ ɹoʊb ɑn hɝ. naɪf əɹ noʊ naɪf, eɪvinhə stɪl tɛndəd tə θɪŋk əz ɪf ʃi wɝ gɑnə faɪt wɪð ə bleɪɾ ən maɪt nid tə muv sʌɾənli. "pʊt ðɪs bæk ɪn ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum," ɪleɪn sɛd, hændɪŋ ði aɪvɝi æŋɡɹil tə ɛsænd. "eɪvinhə, aɪ ɹɪli doʊn θɪŋk wi nid ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ə kɹæk, ən bɝdʒɪt pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn, skaʊlɪŋ. nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni dʒʌmpt, nɑt soʊ suðd əz ðeɪ hæd simd.

Excepting the towel atop her head, Aviendha wore only a wet sheen, and she angrily waved Sephanie away when the woman tried to put her robe on her. Knife or no knife, Aviendha still tended to think as if she were going to fight with a blade and might need to move suddenly. "Put this back in the dressing room," Elayne said, handing the ivory angreal to Essande. "Aviendha, I really don't think we need The door opened a crack, and Birgitte put her head in, scowling. Naris and Sephanie jumped, not so soothed as they had seemed.

"zeɪɾə wɑns tə si ju," bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld əɾ ɪleɪn. "aɪ toʊld əɹ ʃiɾ əv tə weɪt, bʌt - " wɪð ə sʌɾən jɛlp, ʃi stæɡɝɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, kætʃɪŋ əɹ bæləns æftɝ tu stɛps ən wɝlɪŋ tə feɪs ðə wʊmən u hæd pʊʃt hɝ.

"Zaida wants to see you," Birgitte growled at Elayne. "I told her she'd have to wait, but - " With a sudden yelp, she staggered into the room, catching her balance after two steps and whirling to face the woman who had pushed her.

ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn kæɾɪlɝ dɪd nɑt lʊk əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd pʊʃt ɛniwʌn. ði ɛnz ə hɝ ɪntʃɹəkətli nɑɾɪd ɹɛd sæʃ swɝlɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ niz, ʃi ɛntɝd ðə ɹum kɑmli, fɑloʊd baɪ tu wɪndfɪndɝz, wʌn ə hum ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ ɪn ɹæsɔɹiəz æŋɡɹi feɪs. ɔl θɹi sweɪd wən ðeɪ muv nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ əz bɝdʒɪt dɪɾ ɪn əɹ hil buts. zeɪɾə wɑz ʃɔɹt, wɪð stʃɹiks ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ taɪtli kɝl hɛɹ, bʌɾ əɹ dɑɹk feɪs wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz ðət ɡɹu mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl wɪð ðə jɪɹz, ən əɹ bjuɾi oʊnli simd mæɡnəfaɪd baɪ ðə ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn, hɛvi wɪð smɔl mədæljənz, ðət kənɛktəd wʌn ə hɝ fæt ɡoʊldən ɪɹɪŋz tə hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, hɝ ɛɹ wɑz wʌn ə kəmænd. nɑɾ ʌv ɛɹəɡəns, bʌɾ ə ðə nɑlədʒ ðət ʃi wəd bi oʊbeɪd. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz aɪɾ eɪvinhə, stɪl ɡloʊɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ən tʃənɛlz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs taɪɾənd, jɛɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ə mɝmɝ fɹəm ʃilɪn ðət "ði il ɡɝl" wɑz ɹɛɾi tə wiv, ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn saɪlən ən weɪɾəd. ði eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz ɪn ʃilɪnz ɪɹz mɑɹkt əɹ əz wɪndfɪndɝ tə ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs, ən tʃənɛlz ɑnɝ-tʃeɪn kæɹid nɪɹli əz mɛni ɡoʊldən mədæljənz əz ðəɾ ə zeɪɾə hɝsɛlf. boʊθ wɝ wɪmən ʌv əθɔɹəɾi, ən ɪt wɑz pleɪn ɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz ən muvd, jɛt wʌn niɾəd tə noʊ nʌθɪŋ ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ tə noʊ əz sun əz wʌn sɔ ðɛm ðət zeɪɾə dɪn pɑɹid hɛl ðə fɝst spɑt.

The Wavemistress of Clan Catelar did not look as though she had pushed anyone. The ends of her intricately knotted red sash swirling about her knees, she entered the room calmly, followed by two Windfinders, one of whom shut the door in Rasoria's angry face. All three swayed when they moved nearly as much as Birgitte did in her heeled boots. Zaida was short, with streaks of gray in her tightly curled hair, but her dark face was one of those that grew more beautiful with the years, and her beauty only seemed magnified by the golden chain, heavy with small medallions, that connected one of her fat golden earrings to her nose ring. More importantly, her air was one of command. Not of arrogance, but of the knowledge that she would be obeyed. The Windfinders eyed Aviendha, still glowing with the Power, and Chanelle's angular face tightened, yet aside from a murmur from Shielyn that "the Aiel girl" was ready to weave, they remained silent and waited. The eight earrings in Shielyn's ears marked her as Windfinder to a Clan Wavemistress, and Chanelle's honor-chain carried nearly as many golden medallions as that of Zaida herself. Both were women of authority, and it was plain in the way they held themselves and moved, yet one needed to know nothing of the Atha'an Miere to know as soon as one saw them that Zaida din Parede held the first spot.

"jɔɹ buts mʌst əv tʃɹɪp ju, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl," ʃi mɝmɝd wɪð ə smɔl smaɪl ɑn əɹ fʊl lɪps, wʌn dɑɹk tætud hæn tɔɪɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən sɛnt-bɑks ðət dæŋɡəld ɑn əɹ tʃɛst. "klʌmzi θɪŋz, buts." ʃi ən ðə tu wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ bɛɹfʊɾ əz ɔlweɪz. ðə soʊlz ə ði æθɑn maɪɹz fit wɝ əz tʌf əz ʃu-soʊlz, ənbəðɝd baɪ ɹʌf dɛks əɹ koʊl flɔɹ taɪlz. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ɪn ədɪʃən tə ðɛɹ blaʊsəz ən tʃɹaʊzɝz ə bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd sɪlk bɹoʊkeɪdz, itʃ wʊmən wɔɹ ə waɪd stoʊl ə pleɪn waɪt ðət hʌŋ bɪloʊ hɝ weɪst ən ɔlmoʊs hɪɾ əɹ mʌltətuɾ ə nɛkləsɪz. "aɪ wɑz teɪkɪŋ ə bæθ," ɪleɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt si ðət wɪð əɹ hɛɹ dʌn ʌp ən əɹ ɹoʊb klɪŋɪŋ tə hɝ dæmpli. ɛsænd wɑz ɔlmoʊs kwɪvɝɪŋ wɪð ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, wɪtʃ mɛnt ʃi mʌs bi bɪsaɪd hɝsɛlf wɪð fjʊɹi. ɪleɪn fɛl kloʊs tə ɪt hɝsɛlf. "aɪ wɪl bi teɪkɪŋ ə bæθ əɡɛn əz sun əz jə ɡoʊ. əl spik wɪð jə wən aɪ hæv fɪnɪʃt teɪkɪŋ maɪ bæθ. ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt." ðɛɹ! ɪf ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə ʃʌv ɪndə hɝ ɹumz, lɛɾ əm tʃu ɑn ðət fəɹ sɛɹəmoʊni!

"Your boots must have tripped you, Captain-General," she murmured with a small smile on her full lips, one dark tattooed hand toying with the golden scent-box that dangled on her chest. "Clumsy things, boots." She and the two Windfinders were barefoot as always. The soles of the Atha'an Miere's feet were as tough as shoe-soles, unbothered by rough decks or cold floor tiles. Strangely, in addition to their blouses and trousers of brightly colored silk brocades, each woman wore a wide stole of plain white that hung below her waist and almost hid her multitude of necklaces. "I was taking a bath," Elayne said in a tight voice. As if they could not see that with her hair done up and her robe clinging to her damply. Essande was almost quivering with indignation, which meant she must be beside herself with fury. Elayne felt close to it herself. "I will be taking a bath again as soon as you go. I will speak with you when I have finished taking my bath. If it pleases the Light." There! If they were going to shove into her rooms, let them chew on that for ceremony!

"ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn jə ɔlsoʊ, ɪleɪn sədaɪ," zeɪɾə ɹɪplaɪd smuðli. ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ əɾ eɪvinhə, ðoʊ niðɝ ət ðə kəntɪnjuɪŋ laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, sɪns zeɪɾə kəd nɑt tʃænəl, nɔɹ əɾ əɹ nuɾɪti, sɪns ðə si foʊk wɝ kwaɪt kæʒəwəl əbaʊt ðæt, ət list aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə lænmən. "ju hæv nɛvɝ ɪnvaɪɾəd mi tə beɪð wɪð ju, ðoʊ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn kɝɾiəs, bʌt wɪl nɑt spik ə ðæt. aɪ hæv lɝn ðət nɛstə dɪn ɹiz tu munz ɪz dɛd, kɪl baɪ ðə sintʃæn. wi mɔɹn əɹ lɔs." ɔl θɹi wɪmən tʌtʃt ðɛɹ waɪt stoʊlz ən tʌtʃt fɪŋɡɝtɪps tə lɪps, jɛt zeɪɾə simd əz ɪmpeɪʃənt wɪð fɔɹmæləɾi əz ɪleɪn. wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs əɹ spiɾɪŋ ɪts peɪs, ʃi mɪɹli pʊʃt ɑn, ɔlmoʊst ʃɑkɪŋli əbɹʌpt ən tə ðə pɔɪn fəɹ wʌn ə ðə si foʊk.

"The grace of the Light be upon you also, Elayne Sedai," Zaida replied smoothly. She raised an eyebrow at Aviendha, though neither at the continuing light of saidar, since Zaida could not channel, nor at her nudity, since the Sea Folk were quite casual about that, at least out of sight of landmen. "You have never invited me to bathe with you, though it would have been courteous, but we will not speak of that. I have learned that Nesta din Reas Two Moons is dead, killed by the Seanchan. We mourn her loss." All three women touched their white stoles and touched fingertips to lips, yet Zaida seemed as impatient with formality as Elayne. Without raising her voice or speeding its pace, she merely pushed on, almost shockingly abrupt and to the point for one of the Sea Folk.

"ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ mʌs mit tə tʃuz ənʌðɝ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps.

"The First Twelve of the Atha'an Miere must meet to choose another Mistress of the Ships.

wʌɾ ɪz hæpənɪŋ tə ðə wɛs meɪks ɪt klɪɹ ðəɹ kən bi noʊ dɪleɪ." ʃilɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən tʃənɛl ɹeɪzd əɹ pɪɹst sɛn bɑks tə hɝ noʊz əz ɪf tə dʒɹaʊn ðə smɛl ə sʌmθɪŋ. ɪts spaɪsi pɝfjum wɑz ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə slaɪs θɹu ðə sɛn ə ɹoʊz ɔɪl ɪn ðə ɹum. haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ hæd dɪskɹaɪbd wʌt ðeɪ sɛns tə zeɪɾə, ʃi dɪspleɪd noʊ əniz, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt sɝɾənti. hɝ ɡeɪz hɛl stɛɾi ɑn ɪleɪnz feɪs. "wi mʌs bi ɹɛɾi fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ kʌmz, ən fəɹ ðət wi niɾ ə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, jə pɹɑməs twɛnti titʃɝz. aɪ kænɑt teɪk vændin ɪn əɹ ɡɹif, əɹ ju, bʌɾ əl teɪk ði ʌðɝ θɹi wɪð mi. ðə ɹɛst, ðə waɪt taʊɝ oʊz, ən əl ɪkspɛk pɹɑmpt peɪmənt. aɪ hæv sɛn tə ðə sɪstɝz ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn tə si wɛðɝ səm ə ðɛm wɪl mit ðə taʊɝz dɛt, bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt weɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ɹɪplaɪ. ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt, əl beɪð wɪð ði ʌðɝ weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz tənaɪɾ ət ðə hɑɹbɝ ʌv ɪljən."

What is happening to the west makes it clear there can be no delay." Shielyn's mouth tightened, and Chanelle raised her pierced scent box to her nose as if to drown the smell of something. Its spicy perfume was sharp enough to slice through the scent of rose oil in the room. However they had described what they sensed to Zaida, she displayed no unease, or anything but certainty. Her gaze held steady on Elayne's face. "We must be ready for whatever comes, and for that we need a Mistress of the Ships. In the name of the White Tower, you promised twenty teachers. I cannot take Vandene in her grief, or you, but I will take the other three with me. The rest, the White Tower owes, and I will expect prompt payment. I have sent to the sisters at the Silver Swan to see whether some of them will meet the Tower's debt, but I cannot wait on their reply. If it pleases the Light, I will bathe with the other Wavemistresses tonight at the harbor of Illian."

ɪleɪn fɔt vɛɹi hɑɹd tə kip əɹ oʊn feɪs smuð. ðə wʊmən dʒʌst ənaʊns ðət ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə skup ʌp ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪɪŋ ɝaʊn lus ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ən kæɹi ðɛm ɔf? ən ɪt saʊndəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə liv ɛni ʌv ðə wɪndfɪndɝz bɪhaɪnd. ðət meɪɾ ɪleɪnz hɑɹt sɪŋk. əntɪl ɹin ɹɪtɝnd, ðəɹ wɝ sɛvən ə ðə kɪn wɪð səfɪʃən stʃɹɛŋkθ tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt tu ʌv ðoʊz kəd nɑt meɪk wʌn lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə ədmɪɾ ə hɔɹs kɑɹt. wɪθaʊt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, plænz fəɹ kipɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn səplaɪd fɹəm tiɹ ən ɪljən bɪkeɪm pɹɑbləmæɾɪkəl ət bɛst.

Elayne fought very hard to keep her own face smooth. The woman just announced that she intended to scoop up every Aes Sedai lying around loose in Caemlyn and carry them off? And it sounded very much as if she did not intend to leave any of the Windfinders behind. That made Elayne's heart sink. Until Reanne returned, there were seven of the Kin with sufficient strength to weave a gateway, but two of those could not make one large enough to admit a horse cart. Without the Windfinders, plans for keeping Caemlyn supplied from Tear and Illian became problematical at best.

ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn! laɪt, huɛvɝ zeɪɾə hæd sɛnt wəd ɹɪvil ɛvɹi laɪn ə ðə bɑɹɡən ʃi hæd meɪd!

The Silver Swan! Light, whoever Zaida had sent would reveal every line of the bargain she had made!

ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt gɑnə θæŋk əɹ fəɹ spɪlɪŋ ðət mɛs aʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpən. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ hæd soʊ mɛni pɹɑbləmz dʒɹɑpt ɪn əɹ læp ɪn ðə kɔɹs ʌv wʌn ʃɔɹt steɪtmənt.

Egwene was not going to thank her for spilling that mess out into the open. She did not think she had ever had so many problems dropped in her lap in the course of one short statement.

"aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt jəɹ lɔs, ən ði æθɑn maɪɹz lɔs," ʃi sɛd, θɪŋkɪŋ fæst. "nɛstə dɪn ɹiz wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt wʊmən." ʃi hæd bɪn ə paʊɝfəl wʊmən, ɛniweɪ, ən ə vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ pɝsənælɪɾi. ɪleɪn hæd fɛl hæpi tə wɔk əweɪ wɪð mɔɹ ðən əɹ ʃɪft æftɝ əɹ wʌn miɾɪŋ wɪð hɝ. spikɪŋ ə ʃɪfs, ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd taɪm tə dʒɹɛs. zeɪɾə maɪt nɑt weɪt. ʃi bɛltəɾ əɹ ɹoʊb taɪɾɝ. "wi mʌs tɔk. hæv waɪn bɹɔt fəɹ əɹ ɡɛsts, ɛsænd, ən ti fəɹ mi. wik ti," ʃi saɪɾ əɾ ə bɝst ə kɑʃən θɹu ðə bɑn tə bɝdʒɪt. "ɪn ðə smɔlɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. wɪl jə dʒɔɪn mi, weɪvməstʃɹəs?" tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, zeɪɾə mɪɹli nɑɾəd əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs. ðət stɑɹɾəd ɪleɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt zeɪɾəz saɪɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən bɪtwin ðɛm. ðə bɑɹɡənz; ðəɹ wɝ tu, ɹɪli, ən ðət maɪt bi ə ki pɔɪnt.

"I regret your loss, and the Atha'an Miere's loss," she said, thinking fast. "Nesta din Reas was a great woman." She had been a powerful woman, anyway, and a very strong personality. Elayne had felt happy to walk away with more than her shift after her one meeting with her. Speaking of shifts, she could not afford time to dress. Zaida might not wait. She belted her robe tighter. "We must talk. Have wine brought for our guests, Essande, and tea for me. Weak tea," she sighed at a burst of caution through the bond to Birgitte. "In the smaller sitting room. Will you join me, Wavemistress?" To her surprise, Zaida merely nodded as if she had expected this. That started Elayne thinking about Zaida's side of the bargain between them. The bargains; there were two, really, and that might be a key point.

noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðə smɔlɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum tə bi juz fəɹ səm taɪm, soʊ ði ɛɹ hɛld ə tʃɪl ivən æftɝ sɛfæni ɹʌʃt wɪð ə spɑɹk-wil tə laɪt ðə kɪnlɪŋ leɪd bɪniθ splɪɾ oʊk ɑn ðə waɪd waɪt hɑɹθ ən skɝiɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum. fleɪmz lɛpt ʌp fɹəm ðə fætwʊd, kætʃɪŋ ɑn ðə lɔɡ ətɑp ðə faɪɝ-aɪɝnz əz ðə wɪmən ɝeɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðə laɪtli kɑɹv loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɝeɪnʒd ɪn ə sɛmɪsɝkəl ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. wɛl, ɪleɪn ən ðə si foʊk wɪmən ɝeɪd ðɛmsɛlvz, ɪleɪn ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊb kɛɹfəli oʊvɝ əɹ niz ən wɪʃɪŋ zeɪɾə hæd dɪleɪd dʒʌst ən aʊɝ soʊ ʃi kəd bi pɹɑpɝli dʒɹɛst, ðə wɪndfɪndɝz kuli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs tə teɪk ə tʃɛɹ, ðən sɪɾɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ. bɝdʒɪt stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl wɪð əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps ən əɹ fiɾ əpɑɹt, hɝ feɪs ə θʌndɝhɛd. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ ə klɪɹ dɪzaɪɝ tə ɹɪŋ ən æθɑn maɪɹ nɛk. eɪvinhə lin kæʒəwəli əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə saɪdbɔɹdz, ən ivən wən ɛsæn bɹɔɾ əɹ ɹoʊb ən pɔɪntɪdli hɛld ɪɾ aʊt fəɹ hɝ, ʃi mɪɹli pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn ən ɹɪzumd əɹ poʊz wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts.

No one had expected the smaller sitting room to be used for some time, so the air held a chill even after Sephanie rushed with a spark-wheel to light the kindling laid beneath split oak on the wide white hearth and scurried out of the room. Flames leapt up from the fatwood, catching on the log atop the fire-irons as the women arrayed themselves in the lightly carved low-backed chairs arranged in a semicircle in front of the fireplace. Well, Elayne and the Sea Folk women arrayed themselves, Elayne arranging her robe carefully over her knees and wishing Zaida had delayed just an hour so she could be properly dressed, the Windfinders coolly waiting for the Wavemistress to take a chair, then sitting to either side of her. Birgitte stood in front of the writing table with her hands on her hips and her feet apart, her face a thunderhead. The bond carried a clear desire to wring an Atha'an Miere neck. Aviendha leaned casually against one of the sideboards, and even when Essande brought her robe and pointedly held it out for her, she merely put it on and resumed her pose with her arms folded beneath her breasts.

ʃi hæd ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌt ðə tɝɾəl wɑz stɪl ɪn əɹ hænd, ən ɪleɪn səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə paʊɝ əɡɛn ɪn ən ɪnstənt. niðɝ eɪvinhəz koʊld ɡɹin-aɪd stɛɹ nɔɹ bɝdʒɪts skaʊl əfɛktəd ðə si foʊk ɪn ðə list, haʊɛvɝ. ðeɪ wɝ u ðeɪ wɝ, ən ðeɪ nu hu ðeɪ wɝ.

She had released saidar, but the turtle was still in her hand, and Elayne suspected she was ready to embrace the Power again in an instant. Neither Aviendha's cold green-eyed stare nor Birgitte's scowl affected the Sea Folk in the least, however. They were who they were, and they knew who they were.

"ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ pɹɑməs twɛnti titʃɝz," ɪleɪn sɛd, ɛmfəsaɪzɪŋ slaɪtli. zeɪɾə hæd sɛd ðət ʃi hæd bɪn pɹɑməst, ðət ʃi wəd kəlɛk peɪmənt, bʌt ðət bɑɹɡən hæd bɪn meɪd wɪð nɛstə dɪn ɹiz. ʌv kɔɹs, zeɪɾə maɪt bɪliv ʃi wəd bɪkʌm ðə nu mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps hɝsɛlf.

"The Atha'an Miere were promised twenty teachers," Elayne said, emphasizing slightly. Zaida had said that she had been promised, that she would collect payment, but that bargain had been made with Nesta din Reas. Of course, Zaida might believe she would become the new Mistress of the Ships herself.

"pɹɑpɝ titʃɝz, tə bi səlɛktəd baɪ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. aɪ noʊ ðət ði æθɑn maɪɹ pɹaɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɑn miɾɪŋ ðɛɹ bɑɹɡənz ɪn fʊl, ən ðə taʊɝ wɪl miɾ ɪts saɪd, tu. bʌt jə nu wən sɪstɝz hɪɹ əɡɹid tə titʃ, ðəɾ ɪt wɑz tɛmpɝɛɹi. ən ə bɑɹɡən kwaɪɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm ðət meɪd wɪð ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. jə ədmɪɾəd əz mʌtʃ wən jə əɡɹid fəɹ wɪndfɪndɝz tə wiv ɡeɪtweɪz tə bɹɪŋ səplaɪz tə keɪɛmlɪn fɹəm ɪljən ən tɛɹ. ʃʊɹli jə wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɑɾən ɪnvɑlvd ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊn fəɹ ɛni ɹizən ʌðɝ ðən peɪɪŋ ɔf ə bɑɹɡən. bʌɾ ɪf jə ɑɹ livɪŋ, jəɹ hɛlp ɪz əɾ ən ɛnd, ən soʊ ɪz əɹ ɹɪkwaɪɹmən tə titʃ. aɪ fɪɹ jəl hɑɹvəs noʊ titʃɝz ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn, iðɝ. ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪl əv tə weɪɾ əntɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn sɛnz titʃɝz. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə bɑɹɡən meɪd wɪð ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps." ə pɪɾi ʃi kəd nɑt dɪmæn ðeɪ steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪn, bʌɾ ɪt maɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt, ən ɛvɹi ɹizən ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə saʊndəd hɑloʊ. ən ɑɹɡjəmən ðət ʃæɾɝd fəɹ læk ʌv ə sɛntɝ wəɾ oʊnli ɛmboʊldən zeɪɾə.. ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ fɝoʊʃəs hæɡəlɝz.

"Proper teachers, to be selected by the Amyrlin Seat. I know that the Atha'an Miere pride themselves on meeting their bargains in full, and the Tower will meet its side, too. But you knew when sisters here agreed to teach, that it was temporary. And a bargain quite apart from that made with the Mistress of the Ships. You admitted as much when you agreed for Windfinders to weave gateways to bring supplies to Caemlyn from Illian and Tear. Surely you would not have gotten involved in the affairs of the shorebound for any reason other than paying off a bargain. But if you are leaving, your help is at an end, and so is our requirement to teach. I fear you will harvest no teachers at the Silver Swan, either. The Atha'an Miere will have to wait until the Amyrlin sends teachers. According to the bargain made with the Mistress of the Ships." A pity she could not demand they stay away from the inn, but it might already be too late for that, and every reason she could think of sounded hollow. An argument that shattered for lack of a center would only embolden Zaida.. The Atha'an Miere were ferocious hagglers.

skɹupjələs, bʌt fɝoʊʃəs. ʃi hæd tə ɡoʊ vɛɹi sloʊli, vɛɹi kɛɹfəli. "maɪ sɪstɝ əz jə baɪ ði ɪɹ, zeɪɾə dɪn pɑɹid," eɪvinhə tʃɔɹɾəld, slæpɪŋ əɹ θaɪ. "hʌŋ ʌp baɪ ði æŋkəlz, ɪn fækt." ðət wɑz ə si foʊk pʌnɪʃmən ðət ʃi faʊn ɪnkɹɛɾəbli əmjuzɪŋ, fəɹ səm ɹizən.

Scrupulous, but ferocious. She had to go very slowly, very carefully. "My sister has you by the ear, Zaida din Parede," Aviendha chortled, slapping her thigh. "Hung up by the ankles, in fact." That was a Sea Folk punishment that she found incredibly amusing, for some reason.

ɪleɪn staɪfəld ə bɝst ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən. eɪvinhə ɛndʒɔɪd tʃænsəz tə twik ðə si foʊks noʊzɪz - ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn waɪl ðeɪ wɝ fliɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ ən nɛvɝ ɹɪli stɑpt - bʌt ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɪt.

Elayne stifled a burst of irritation. Aviendha enjoyed chances to tweak the Sea Folk's noses - she had begun while they were fleeing Ebou Dar and never really stopped - but this was no time for it.

tʃənɛl stɪfənd, hɝ kɑm feɪs sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə ə ɡlɛɹ. ðə lin wʊmən hæd bɪn ðə bʌɾ ʌv eɪvinhəz noʊz-twikɪŋ mɔɹ ðən wʌns, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə ɹɪɡɹɛɾəbəl ɛpəsoʊɾ ɪnvɑlvɪŋ uskaɪ, ə vɛɹi poʊɾənt il dʒɹɪŋk. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ æktʃəli  sɝaʊndəd hɝ! zeɪɾə kəd nɑt si ðæt, bʌt ʃi nu əbaʊt ði uskaɪ ən tʃənɛl biɪŋ kæɹid tə hɝ bɛd, sɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə hoʊl weɪ, ən ʃi ɹeɪzd ə pɝɛmptɝi hæn təwɔɹd ðə wɪndfɪndɝ. ðə ɡloʊ feɪɾəd, ən tʃənɛlz feɪs dɑɹkənd. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə blʌʃ əɹ æŋɡɝ.

Chanelle stiffened, her calm face sinking into a glare. The lean woman had been the butt of Aviendha's nose-tweaking more than once, including a regrettable episode involving oosquai, a very potent Aiel drink. The glow of saidar actually surrounded her! Zaida could not see that, but she knew about the oosquai and Chanelle being carried to her bed, sicking up the whole way, and she raised a peremptory hand toward the Windfinder. The glow faded, and Chanelle's face darkened. It might have been a blush or anger.

"ɔl ðət jə seɪ meɪ bi soʊ," zeɪɾə sɛd, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɪnsʌltɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli sɛd tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. "ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz nɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðæt. ʃi əɡɹid tə bi wʌn ə ðə titʃɝz lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn, ən ʃɪl ɡoʊ wɪð mi tə kəntɪnju hɝ titʃɪŋ." ɪleɪn dʒɹu ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə ɑɹɡju zeɪɾə aʊɾ ə ðɪs. ə ɡɹeɪt pɑɹɾ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɪnfluəns ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ðə fæk ðət ðə taʊɝ kɛpt ɪts wɝɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə si foʊk. ðəɾ ɪt wɑz noʊn tə kip ɪts wɝd. oʊ, pipəl sɛd jə hæd tə lɪsən kɛɹfəli tə bi ʃʊɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd pɹɑməst wʌt jə θɔt ʃi hæd, ən ðət wɑz ɔfən tʃɹu, bʌt wʌns ðə pɹɑməs wɑz klɪɹ, ɪt wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz ən oʊθ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt. ət lis ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ nɑt laɪkli tə lɛt mɛɝɪlɪl ɡɛɾ əweɪ. ðeɪ hɑɹdli lɛɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ saɪt. "ju meɪ hæv tə ɹɪtɝn əɹ tə mi, ɪf aɪ hæv pɝtɪkjəlɝ niɾ ə hɝ." ɪf vændin ən ðə tu hɛlpɝz faʊn pɹuf ðət ʃi wɑz blæk ədʒɑ. "ɪf ðət hæpənz, əl ɝeɪnʒ ə ɹɪpleɪsmənt." ən u ðət kəd bi, ʃi hæd noʊ aɪdiə. "ʃi hæz ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ jɪɹ tə sɝv. ət list ə jɪɹ, baɪ ðə bɑɹɡən." zeɪɾə dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ɪf meɪkɪŋ ə kənsɛʃən. "bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz jə ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ əɹ ɹɪpleɪsmən mʌs kʌm bɪfɔɹ ʃi livz. əl nɑt lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɪn əɹ pleɪs." "aɪ səpoʊz ðət wɪl du," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. ɪt wəd blʌɾi wɛl əv tə, sɪns ʃi hæd noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs!

"All that you say may be so," Zaida said, which was not far from insulting, especially said to an Aes Sedai. "In any event, Merilille was not part of that. She agreed to be one of the teachers long before she reached Caemlyn, and she will go with me to continue her teaching." Elayne drew a long breath. She could not even try to argue Zaida out of this. A great part of the White Tower's influence rested on the fact that the Tower kept its word as surely as the Sea Folk. That it was known to keep its word. Oh, people said you had to listen carefully to be sure an Aes Sedai had promised what you thought she had, and that was often true, but once the promise was clear, it was as good as an oath under the Light. At least the Windfinders were not likely to let Merilille get away. They hardly let her out of their sight. "You may have to return her to me, if I have particular need of her." If Vandene and the two helpers found proof that she was Black Ajah. "If that happens, I will arrange a replacement." And who that could be, she had no idea. "She has the rest of her year to serve. At least a year, by the bargain." Zaida gestured as if making a concession. "But so long as you understand that her replacement must come before she leaves. I will not let her go without another in her place." "I suppose that will do," Elayne replied calmly. It would bloody well have to, since she had no other choice!

zeɪɾə smaɪl feɪnli ən lɛt ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃ. tʃənɛl ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fit, bʌt mɔɹ ɪn ɪmpeɪʃəns ðən əz ɪf tə ɹaɪz, ən ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs dɪd nɑt stɝ. pleɪnli ʃi wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, ɪntɛndəɾ ənʌðɝ bɑɹɡən, ən pleɪnli ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪleɪn tə spik fɝst. ɪleɪn sɛt hɝsɛlf tə aʊtweɪt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ðə faɪɝ hæd bɪɡʌn tə bleɪz ən kɹækəl, sɛndɪŋ spɑɹks ʌp ðə tʃɪmni ən ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ ə faɪn wɔɹmθ ɪndə ðə ɹum, bʌɾ əɹ dæmp ɹoʊb əbzɔɹb ðə tʃɪl ɪn ði ɛɹ ən tʃɹænsfɝɾ ɪt tə hɝ skɪn.

Zaida smiled faintly and let the silence stretch. Chanelle shifted her feet, but more in impatience than as if to rise, and the Wavemistress did not stir. Plainly she wanted something more, intended another bargain, and plainly she wanted Elayne to speak first. Elayne set herself to outwait the other woman. The fire had begun to blaze and crackle, sending sparks up the chimney and radiating a fine warmth into the room, but her damp robe absorbed the chill in the air and transferred it to her skin.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə koʊld wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt haʊ wɝ jə səpoʊz tə ɪɡnɔɹ biɪŋ koʊld ən wɛt? ʃi mɛt zeɪɾəz ɡeɪz lɛvəli ən mætʃt əɹ taɪni smaɪl. ɛsæn ɹɪtɝnd, fɑloʊd baɪ nɛɹɪs ən sɛfæni kæɹɪŋ ɹoʊpwɝk tʃɹeɪz, ðə wʌn wɪð ə sɪlvɝ tipɑɾ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə laɪən ən θɪn ɡɹin kʌps ə si foʊk pɔɹsələn, ði ʌðɝ hæmɝd sɪlvɝ kʌps ən ə tɔl-nɛkt waɪn pɪtʃɝ ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ði ɝoʊmə ʌv spaɪsəz. ɛvɹiwʌn tʊk waɪn, ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪleɪn, hu wɑz nɛvɝ ɔfɝd ðə tʃɔɪs. piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ ti, ʃi saɪd. ʃi kəd si ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə kʌp kwaɪt klɪɹli. ɪf ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪɾ ɛni wikɝ, ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɪv əɹ wɔɾɝ!

Ignoring the cold was all very well, but how were you supposed to ignore being cold and wet? She met Zaida's gaze levelly and matched her tiny smile. Essande returned, followed by Naris and Sephanie carring ropework trays, the one with a silver teapot in the shape of a lion and thin green cups of Sea Folk porcelain, the other hammered silver cups and a tall-necked wine pitcher that gave off the aroma of spices. Everyone took wine, except for Elayne, who was never offered the choice. Peering into her tea, she sighed. She could see the bottom of the cup quite clearly. If they made it any weaker, they might as well give her water!

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, eɪvinhə stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum tə sɛɾ əɹ waɪnkʌp bæk ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ ətɑp wʌn ə ðə saɪdbɔɹdz ən pɔɹ hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə nɑɾ ən ə smaɪl kəmbaɪnɪŋ sɪmpəθi wɪð ə sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi ɹɪli pɹəfɝd wɔɾɝi ti tə waɪn. ɪleɪn smaɪl bæk ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf.

After a moment, Aviendha strode across the room to set her winecup back on the tray atop one of the sideboards and pour herself a cup of tea. She gave Elayne a nod and a smile combining sympathy with a suggestion that she really preferred watery tea to wine. Elayne smiled back in spite of herself.

fɝst-sɪstɝz ʃɛɹd ðə bæɾ əz wɛl əz ðə ɡʊd. bɝdʒɪt ɡɹɪn oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə hɝ sɪlvɝ kʌp, ən pɹəsiɾəd tə ɛmpti hæf ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ə ɡʌlp. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ əɹ əmjuzmən ət ðə ɡɹʌmpinəs ʃi fɛl fɹəm ɪleɪn. ən ɪt stɪl kæɹiɾ əɹ hɛdeɪk, ɪn noʊ weɪ ɹədust. ɪleɪn ɹʌbd əɹ tɛmpəl. ʃi ʃʊɾə ɪnsɪstəd ðət mɛɝɪlɪl hil ðə wʊmən əz sun əz ʃi hæd sin hɝ. ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə kɪn aʊtstʃɹɪp mɛɝɪlɪl wən ɪt keɪm tə hilɪŋ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ði oʊnli sɪstɝ ɪn ðə pæləs wɪð ə hæfweɪ disən əbɪləɾi.

First-sisters shared the bad as well as the good. Birgitte grinned over the top of her silver cup, and proceeded to empty half of it in a gulp. The bond carried her amusement at the grumpiness she felt from Elayne. And it still carried her headache, in no way reduced. Elayne rubbed her temple. She should have insisted that Merilille Heal the woman as soon as she had seen her. A number of the Kin outstripped Merilille when it came to Healing, but she was the only sister in the palace with a halfway decent ability.

"ju hæv ɡɹeɪt niɾ ʌv wɪmən tə meɪk ðiz ɡeɪtweɪz," zeɪɾə sɛd sʌɾənli. hɝ fʊl maʊθ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ smaɪlɪŋ. ʃi dɪslaɪk hævɪŋ spoʊkən fɝst.

"You have great need of women to make these gateways," Zaida said suddenly. Her full mouth was no longer smiling. She disliked having spoken first.

ɪleɪn sɪpt əɹ ɹɛtʃɪɾ ɪkskjus fəɹ ti ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ. "ɪt maɪt pliz ðə laɪt ðəɾ aɪ kəd liv wʌn əɹ tu wɪnfmdɝz hɪɹ," zeɪɾə wɛn ɑn. "fɔɹ ə sɛt taɪm." ɪleɪn ɹɪŋkəld əɹ bɹaʊ əz ðoʊ kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. ʃi niɾəd ðoʊz blʌɾi wɪmən, ən mɔɹ ðən wʌn əɹ tu. "wʌt wəd jə æsk ɪn ɹɪtɝn?" ʃi sɛd faɪnəli.

Elayne sipped her wretched excuse for tea and said nothing. "It might please the Light that I could leave one or two Windfmders here," Zaida went on. "For a set time." Elayne wrinkled her brow as though considering. She needed those bloody women, and more than one or two. "What would you ask in return?" she said finally.

"wʌn skwɛɹ maɪl ə læn ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn. ɡʊd lænd, maɪnd. nɑt mɑɹʃi əɹ bɑi. ɪts tə bi æθɑn maɪɹ læn ɪn pɝpɪtʃjuɪɾi. ʌndɝ əɹ lɔz, nɑɾ ændɝz," ʃi æɾəd əz ɪf ðət wɝ ə smɔl æftɝθɑt hɑɹdli wɝθ mɛnʃənɪŋ.

"One square mile of land on the River Erinin. Good land, mind. Not marshy or boggy. It is to be Atha'an Miere land in perpetuity. Under our laws, not Andor's," she added as if that were a small afterthought hardly worth mentioning.

ɪleɪn tʃoʊkt ɑn əɹ ti. ði æθɑn maɪɹ heɪɾəd livɪŋ ðə si, heɪɾəd biɪŋ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ʌv ɪt.

Elayne choked on her tea. The Atha'an Miere hated leaving the sea, hated being out of sight of it.

ən zeɪɾə wɑz æskɪŋ fəɹ læn ə θaʊzən maɪlz fɹəm ðə nɪɹəst sɔlt wɔɾɝ? æskɪŋ fəɹ ɪt tə bi siɾəd æbsəlutli, ət ðæt. kɛɹhinɪn ən mʊɹændiənz ən ivən ɔltɑɹənz hæd blɛd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk bɪts ʌv ændɝ, ən ændɔɹənz hæd blɛd tə kip əm aʊt. stɪl, wʌn skwɛɹ maɪl wɑz ə smɔl bɪt, ən ə smɔl pɹaɪs tə kip keɪɛmlɪn səplaɪd. nɑt ðət ʃi wəd lɛt zeɪɾə noʊ ðæt. ən ɪf ðə si foʊk bɪɡæn tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ dɝɛkli ɪndə ændɝ, ðən ændɔɝən ɡʊdz wəd bi eɪbəl tə muv ɪn si foʊk bɑɾəmz ɛvɹiwɛɹ ðə si foʊk seɪld, ən ðət wɑz ɛvɹiwɛɹ. zeɪɾə ʃʊɹli nu ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn lɛɾɪŋ əɹ noʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd θɔɾ ʌv ɪt. ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn ɝdʒ kɑʃən, jɛt ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz fəɹ boʊlnəs, əz bɝdʒɪt ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛniwʌn.

And Zaida was asking for land a thousand miles from the nearest salt water? Asking for it to be ceded absolutely, at that. Cairhienin and Murandians and even Altarans had bled trying to take bits of Andor, and Andorans had bled to keep them out. Still, one square mile was a small bit, and a small price to keep Caemlyn supplied. Not that she would let Zaida know that. And if the Sea Folk began trading directly into Andor, then Andoran goods would be able to move in Sea Folk bottoms everywhere the Sea Folk sailed, and that was everywhere. Zaida surely knew that already, but there was no point in letting her know that Elayne had thought of it. The Warder bond urged caution, yet there were times for boldness, as Birgitte should know better than anyone.

"səmtaɪmz ti ɡoʊz daʊn ðə ɹɔŋ weɪ." nɑɾ ə laɪ; mɪɹli ən ɪveɪʒən. "fɔɹ ə skwɛɹ maɪl ʌv ændɝ, aɪ dɪzɝv mɔɹ ðən tu wɪndfɪndɝz. ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɡɑt twɛnti titʃɝz ən mɔɹ fəɹ hɛlp juzɪŋ ðə boʊl ə ðə wɪnz, ən wən ðeɪ ɡoʊ jəl əv twɛnti tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm. juv twɛnti-wʌn wɪndfɪndɝz wɪð ju. fəɹ ə maɪl ʌv ændɝ, aɪ ʃəɾ əv ɔl twɛnti-wʌn, ən twɛnti-wʌn mɔɹ ɪn ðɛɹ pleɪsəz wən ðeɪ liv, fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ titʃ si foʊk." bɛs nɑt tə lɛt ðə wʊmən θɪŋk ðət wɑz əɹ weɪ ʌv ɹɪdʒɛktɪŋ ði ɔfɝ aʊɾ ə hænd. "ʌv kɔɹs, ðə nɔɹməl kʌstəmz duɾiz wəɾ əplaɪ tə ɛni ɡʊdz muvɪŋ ɔf ðɪs læn ɪndə ændɝ."

"Sometimes tea goes down the wrong way." Not a lie; merely an evasion. "For a square mile of Andor, I deserve more than two Windfinders. The Atha'an Miere got twenty teachers and more for help using the Bowl of the Winds, and when they go you will have twenty to replace them. You have twenty-one Windfinders with you. For a mile of Andor, I should have all twenty-one, and twenty-one more in their places when they leave, for as long as Aes Sedai teach Sea Folk." Best not to let the woman think that was her way of rejecting the offer out of hand. "Of course, the normal customs duties would apply to any goods moving off this land into Andor."

zeɪɾə ɹeɪzd əɹ sɪlvɝ kʌp tə hɝ maʊθ, ən wən ʃi loʊɝɾ ɪt, ʃi wɔɹ ðə taɪniəst smaɪl. jɛɾ ɪleɪn θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə smaɪl ə ɹɪlif ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaɪəmf. "ɡʊdz muvɪŋ ɪndə ændɝ, bʌt nɑt ɡʊdz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑntu əɹ lænd. aɪ maɪt liv θɹi wɪndfɪndɝz. fəɹ hæf ə jɪɹ, seɪ. ən ðeɪ mʌs nɑt bi juzd ɪn faɪɾɪŋ. əl nɑɾ əv maɪ pipəl daɪ fəɹ ju, ən əl nɑɾ əv ʌðɝ ændɔɹənz æŋɡɹi əɾ əs kəz si foʊk əv kɪl səm ə ðɛm."

Zaida raised her silver cup to her mouth, and when she lowered it, she wore the tiniest smile. Yet Elayne thought it was a smile of relief rather than triumph. "Goods moving into Andor, but not goods coming from the river onto our land. I might leave three Windfinders. For half a year, say. And they must not be used in fighting. I will not have my people die for you, and I will not have other Andorans angry at us because Sea Folk have killed some of them."

"ðeɪ wɪl bi æskt oʊnli tə meɪk ɡeɪtweɪz," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ðoʊ ðeɪ mʌs meɪk əm wɛɹɛvɝ aɪ ɹikwaɪɝ." laɪt! əz ɪf ʃi ɪntɛndəd juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən! ðə si foʊk dɪd soʊ wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛkən θɔt, bʌt ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ vɛɹi hɑɹd tə bɪheɪv əz ɛɡwin dɪmændəd, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi teɪkən ðə θɹi oʊðz. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf ʃi blæstəd ðoʊz kæmps aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ, əɹ əlaʊɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls tə, nɑɾ ə haʊs ɪn ændɝ wəd stænd wɪð hɝ. "ðeɪ mʌst steɪ əntɪl maɪ kɹaʊn ɪz sɪkjʊɹ, wɛðɝ ðəɾ ɪz hæf ə jɪɹ əɹ lɔŋɡɝ." ðə kɹaʊn ʃəd bi hɝz ɪn mʌtʃ lɛs taɪm, bʌɾ əz əɹ oʊl nɝs lini juz tə seɪ, jə kaʊntəd jəɹ plʌmz ɪn ðə bæskət, nɑɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹi. wʌns ðə kɹaʊn wɑz hɝz, ðoʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt nid wɪndfɪndɝz tə səplaɪ ðə sɪɾi, ən ɪn ɔl tʃɹuθ, ʃi wəd bi hæpi tə si ðɛɹ bæks. "bʌt θɹi ɪz nɑt nɪɹli ɪnʌf. jəl wɑnt ʃilɪn, sɪns ʃiz jəɹ wɪndfɪndɝ. əl kip ðə ɹɛst."

"They will be asked only to make gateways," Elayne said, "though they must make them wherever I require." Light! As if she intended using the One Power as a weapon! The Sea Folk did so without a second thought, but she was trying very hard to behave as Egwene demanded, as though she had already taken the Three Oaths. Besides, if she blasted those camps outside the walls with saidar, or allowed anyone else to, not a House in Andor would stand with her. "They must stay until my crown is secure, whether that is half a year or longer." The crown should be hers in much less time, but as her old nurse Lini used to say, you counted your plums in the basket, not on the tree. Once the crown was hers, though, she would not need Windfinders to supply the city, and in all truth, she would be happy to see their backs. "But three is not nearly enough. You will want Shielyn, since she is your Windfinder. I will keep the rest."

ðə mədæljənz ɑn zeɪɾəz ɑnɝ-tʃeɪn sweɪd dʒɛnli əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "tɑlɑn ən mɛtʃɹə ɑɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz stɪl. ðeɪ mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ði ʌðɝz əv duɾiz, tu. fɔɹ maɪt bi spɛɹɾ əntɪl jəɹ kɹaʊn ɪz sɪkjʊɹ."

The medallions on Zaida's honor-chain swayed gently as she shook her head. "Talaan and Metarra are apprentices still. They must return to their training. The others have duties, too. Four might be spared until your crown is secure."

fɹəm ðəɹ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə mæɾɝ ə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ. ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə kip ði əpɹɛntəsɪz, ən wɪndfɪndɝz tə klæn weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz kəd nɑt bi spɛɹɾ iðɝ, wɪtʃ ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. moʊst weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz juz ðɛɹ wɪndfɪndɝz ən sɔɹdmæstɝz əz kloʊs ædvaɪzɝz, ən wəd bi pɑɹɾəd fɹəm wʌn əz izəli əz ʃi wəd bi pɑɹɾəd fɹəm bɝdʒɪt. zeɪɾə tʃɹaɪd tə ɪkskluɾ ʌðɝz əz wɛl, sətʃ əz wɪndfɪndɝz u sɝvd ɑn lɑɹdʒ vɛsəlz laɪk ɹeɪkɝz ən skɪmɝz, bʌt ðət wʊɾə dɪskwɑləfaɪd ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ən ɪleɪn ɹəfjuzd, ən ɹəfjuz tə kʌm daʊn ɪn əɹ dɪmænz ənlɛs zeɪɾə keɪm ʌp ɪn əɹ ɔfɝz. wɪtʃ ðə wʊmən dɪd sloʊli, ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ ɛvɹi kənsɛʃən. bʌt nɑt soʊ sloʊli əz ɪleɪn maɪɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd. klɪɹli, ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs niɾəd ðɪs bɑɹɡən əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi hɝsɛlf niɾəd wɪmən u kəd wiv ɡeɪtweɪz. "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, ɪts əɡɹid," ʃi wɑz eɪbəl tə seɪ ət læst, kɪsɪŋ ðə fɪŋɡɝtɪps ə hɝ ɹaɪt hæn ən linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə pɹɛs əm tə zeɪɾəz lɪps. eɪvinhə ɡɹɪnd, ɑbviəsli ɪmpɹɛst. bɝdʒɪt kɛpt ə smuð feɪs, bʌt ðə bɑn sɛd ʃi faʊn ɪt hɑɹd tə bɪliv ɪleɪn hæd kʌm aʊt soʊ wɛl.

From there it was just a matter of bargaining. Elayne had never expected to keep the apprentices, and Windfinders to Clan Wavemistresses could not be spared either, which she had expected. Most Wavemistresses used their Windfinders and Swordmasters as close advisors, and would be parted from one as easily as she would be parted from Birgitte. Zaida tried to exclude others as well, such as Windfinders who served on large vessels like rakers and skimmers, but that would have disqualified the greater number right there, and Elayne refused, and refused to come down in her demands unless Zaida came up in her offers. Which the woman did slowly, grudging every concession. But not so slowly as Elayne might have expected. Clearly, the Wavemistress needed this bargain as much as she herself needed women who could weave gateways. "Under the Light, it is agreed," she was able to say at last, kissing the fingertips of her right hand and leaning forward to press them to Zaida's lips. Aviendha grinned, obviously impressed. Birgitte kept a smooth face, but the bond said she found it hard to believe Elayne had come out so well.

"ɪɾ ɪz əɡɹid, ʌndɝ ðə laɪt," zeɪɾə mɝmɝd. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ɪleɪnz lɪps wɝ hɑɹɾ ən kælʌzd, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv hɔld ɑn ə ɹoʊp hɝsɛlf ɪn mɛni jɪɹz. ʃi lʊkt kwaɪt sæɾəsfaɪd fəɹ ə wʊmən u hæd jildəd naɪn ə ðə fɔɹtin wɪndfɪndɝz u hæd bɪn ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɪleɪn wʌndɝd haʊ mɛni ʌv ðoʊz naɪn wəd bi wɪmən huz ʃɪps hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. luzɪŋ ə ʃɪp wɑz ə sɪɹiəs mæɾɝ əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ, wʌtɛvɝ ðə ɹizən, ən meɪbi kɑz ɪnʌf tə wɑnə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm hoʊm ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ.

"It is agreed, under the Light," Zaida murmured. Her fingers on Elayne's lips were hard and callused, though she could not have hauled on a rope herself in many years. She looked quite satisfied for a woman who had yielded nine of the fourteen Windfinders who had been on the table. Elayne wondered how many of those nine would be women whose ships had been destroyed by the Seanchan in Ebou Dar. Losing a ship was a serious matter among the Atha'an Miere, whatever the reason, and maybe cause enough to want to stay away from home a little longer. No matter.

tʃənɛl lʊkt ɡlʌm, hɝ tætud hænz taɪɾ ɑn ðə niz ə hɝ ɹɛd bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz, jɛt nɑt soʊ ɡlʌm əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm ə si foʊk wʊmən u wəɾ əv tə ɹɪmeɪn əʃɔɹ ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ.

Chanelle looked glum, her tattooed hands tight on the knees of her red brocaded trousers, yet not so glum as might be expected from a Sea Folk woman who would have to remain ashore a while longer.

ʃi wɑz tə kəmæn ðə wɪndfɪndɝz u steɪd, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt ðət zeɪɾə hæɾ æksiɾɪd tə hɝ biɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪleɪnz əθɔɹəɾi, ən bɝdʒɪts. ðəɹ wɝ tə bi noʊ mɔɹ si foʊk stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pæləs əz ɪf ðeɪ oʊn ɪɾ ən meɪkɪŋ dɪmænz lɛft ən ɹaɪt. bʌt ðɛn, ɪleɪn səspɛktəd ðət zeɪɾə hæd kʌm tə ðɪs miɾɪŋ noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd liv səm ə hɝ pɑɹɾi bɪhaɪnd, ən tʃənɛl hæd kʌm noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd kəmæn ðɛm. ðət hɑɹdli mæɾɝd, iðɝ, nɔɹ dɪɾ ɪt mæɾɝ wʌɾ ædvæntɪdʒ zeɪɾə hoʊp tə ɡeɪn təwɔɹd bɪkʌmɪŋ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. ðət ʃi sɔ səm wɑz klɪɹ əz ɡʊd ɡlæs. ɔl ðət mæɾɝd wɑz ðət keɪɛmlɪn wəd nɑt ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi. ðəɾ ən ðə . . . ðə blʌɾi bikən stɪl bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə wɛst. noʊ, ʃi wəd bi ə kwin, ən ʃi kəd nɑt bi ə munstʃɹʌk ɡɝl. keɪɛmlɪn ən ændɝ wɝ ɔl ðət kəd mæɾɝ.

She was to command the Windfinders who stayed, and she did not like it that Zaida had acceded to her being under Elayne's authority, and Birgitte's. There were to be no more Sea Folk striding about the palace as if they owned it and making demands left and right. But then, Elayne suspected that Zaida had come to this meeting knowing she would leave some of her party behind, and Chanelle had come knowing she would command them. That hardly mattered, either, nor did it matter what advantage Zaida hoped to gain toward becoming Mistress of the Ships. That she saw some was clear as good glass. All that mattered was that Caemlyn would not go hungry. That and the . . . the bloody beacon still blazing in the west. No, she would be a queen, and she could not be a moonstruck girl. Caemlyn and Andor were all that could matter.

tʃæptɝ θɝtin

CHAPTER 13

haɪ sits zeɪɾə ən ðə tu wɪndfɪndɝz dɪpɑɹɾəd fɹəm ɪleɪnz əpɑɹtməns, ɡɹeɪsfəl ən aʊtwɝdli ənhɝid bʌt wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz lɪɾəl sɛɹəmoʊni əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɛntɝd, ə bɛɹ wɪʃ ðət ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪleɪn ən si hɝ seɪf. fəɹ æθɑn maɪɹ, ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. ɪleɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ ɪf zeɪɾə dɪɾ ɪndid wɑnə bi ðə nɛks mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, ðə wʊmən hæɾ ə ɹaɪvəl ʃi hoʊp tə stil ə mɑɹtʃ ɑn. ɪt maɪt bi wɛl fəɹ ændɝ ɪf zeɪɾə dɪɾ əteɪn ði æθɑn maɪɹ θɹoʊn, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ðə si foʊk kɔld ɪt; bɑɹɡən əɹ noʊ bɑɹɡən, ʃi wəɾ ɔlweɪz bi əwɛɹ ðəɾ ændɝ hæd hɛlp hɝ, ən ðət hæd tə bi fəɹ ðə ɡʊd. ðoʊ ɪf ʃi feɪld, hɝ ɹaɪvəl wəd bi əwɛɹ ʌv wɛɹ ændɝz feɪvɝ hæd ɡɔn, tu. stɪl, ɪt wɑz ɔl ɪf ən meɪbi. hɪɹ ən naʊ wɑz ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ɔltəɡɛðɝ.

High Seats Zaida and the two Windfinders departed from Elayne's apartments, graceful and outwardly unhurried but with almost as little ceremony as they had entered, a bare wish that the Light illumine Elayne and see her safe. For Atha'an Miere, that was almost rushing off without a word. Elayne decided that if Zaida did indeed want to be the next Mistress of the Ships, the woman had a rival she hoped to steal a march on. It might be well for Andor if Zaida did attain the Atha'an Miere throne, or whatever the Sea Folk called it; bargain or no bargain, she would always be aware that Andor had helped her, and that had to be for the good. Though if she failed, her rival would be aware of where Andor's favor had gone, too. Still, it was all if and maybe. Here and now was another thing altogether.

"aɪ də nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛniwʌn tə mænhændəl ən æmbæsəɾɝ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli wʌns ðə dɔɹz hæd kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, "bʌɾ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ aɪ də ɪkspɛk ðə pɹaɪvəsi ʌv maɪ ɹumz. ivən æmbæsəɾɝz ɑɹ nɑt tə bi əlaʊd sɪmpli tə wɑndɝ ɪn. æm aɪ ʌndɝstʊd?"

"I do not expect anyone to manhandle an ambassador," she said quietly once the doors had closed behind them, "but in the future I do expect the privacy of my rooms. Even ambassadors are not to be allowed simply to wander in. Am I understood?"

ɹæsɔɹiə nɑɾəd, hɝ feɪs wʊɾən, bʌt baɪ ðə kʌlɝ ðət flæʃt ɪndə hɝ tʃiks, ʃi fɛl ðə mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ə hævɪŋ lɛt ðə si foʊk pæs əz kinli əz bɝdʒɪt, ən ðə bɑnd . . . ɹɪθd. . . əntɪl ɪleɪn fɛlt əɹ oʊn feɪs ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɹɛd wɪð ə stɪŋɪŋ ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. "ju dɪd nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ, ɪɡzækli, bʌt doʊn lɛɾ ɪt hæpən əɡɛn." laɪt, naʊ ʃi saʊndəɾ ə doʊlt! "wi wɪl spik noʊ mɔɹ ʌv ɪt," ʃi sɛd stɪfli. oʊ, bɝn bɝdʒɪɾ ən ðə bɑnd! ðeɪ wʊɾə hæd tə ɹɛsəl wɪð zeɪɾə tə stɑp hɝ, bʌɾ æɾɪŋ boʊn-dip hjumɪlieɪʃən tə ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz hɛdeɪk wɑz paɪlɪŋ ɪnsəlt ɑn ɪnʒɝi! ən eɪvinhə hæd noʊ kɔl tə ɡɹɪn ɪn ðət . . . ðət smɑɹmi weɪ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wən əɹ haʊ hɝ sɪstɝ hæd lɝn ðət ʃi ən bɝdʒɪt səmtaɪmz ɹəflɛktəd wʌn ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ eɪvinhə faʊn ðə hoʊl θɪŋ væsli əmjuzɪŋ. hɝ sɛns ə hjumɝ kəd bi ɹʌf ət taɪmz.

Rasoria nodded, her face wooden, but by the color that flashed into her cheeks, she felt the mortification of having let the Sea Folk pass as keenly as Birgitte, and the bond . . . writhed. . . until Elayne felt her own face growing red with a stinging embarrassment. "You did nothing wrong, exactly, but don't let it happen again." Light, now she sounded a dolt! "We will speak no more of it," she said stiffly. Oh, burn Birgitte and the bond! They would have had to wrestle with Zaida to stop her, but adding bone-deep humiliation to the other woman's headache was piling insult on injury! And Aviendha had no call to grin in that . . . that smarmy way. Elayne did not know when or how her sister had learned that she and Birgitte sometimes reflected one another, but Aviendha found the whole thing vastly amusing. Her sense of humor could be rough at times.

"aɪ θɪŋk jə tu wɪl meɪk itʃ ʌðɝ mɛlt, wʌn deɪ," ʃi sɛd, læfɪŋ. "bʌt ðɛn, jə ɔlɹɛɾi pleɪd ðət dʒoʊk, bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən." bɝdʒɪt skaʊld ət hɝ, sʌɾən əlɑɹm kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪmbɛɹəsmən ɪn ðə bɑnd, ən ʃi ɹɪtɝn sətʃ ə lʊk ʌv ɪnəsəns ɪt simd əɹ aɪz maɪt fɔl aʊɾ ə hɝ feɪs.

"I think you two will make each other melt, one day," she said, laughing. "But then, you already played that joke, Birgitte Trahelion." Birgitte scowled at her, sudden alarm crushing embarrassment in the bond, and she returned such a look of innocence it seemed her eyes might fall out of her face.

bɛɾɝ nɑt tə æsk, ɪleɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd. wən jə æsk kwɛstʃənz, lini juz tə seɪ, ðən juv tə hɪɹ ði ænsɝz wɛðɝ jə wɑnə əɹ nɑt. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ, nɑt wɪð ɹæsɔɹiə stuɾiəsli ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ buts ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɪn ði æntəɹum feɪlɪŋ tə pɹitɛnd nɑt tə bi lɪsnɪŋ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɹilaɪz haʊ pɹɛʃəs pɹaɪvəsi wɑz əntɪl ʃi lɔst ɪt kəmplitli.

Better not to ask, Elayne decided. When you ask questions, Lini used to say, then you have to hear the answers whether you want to or not. She did not want to hear, not with Rasoria studiously examining the floor tiles in front of her boots and the rest of the Guardswomen in the anteroom failing to pretend not to be listening. She had never realized how precious privacy was until she lost it completely.

nɪɹ ɪnʌf kəmplitli, ɛniweɪ. "aɪ æm gɑnə fɪnɪʃ maɪ bæθ naʊ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, wʌt dʒoʊk hæd bɝdʒɪt pleɪɾ ɑn hɝ? sʌmθɪŋ ðət meɪɾ əɹ . . . mɛlt? ɪt kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mʌtʃ ɪf ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz.

Near enough completely, anyway. "I am going to finish my bath now," she said calmly. Blood and ashes, what joke had Birgitte played on her? Something that made her . . . melt? It could not have been much if she still did not know what it was.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðə bæθ wɔɾɝ hæd ɡɔn koʊld. tɛpɪd, ɛniweɪ. hɑɹdli ɛniθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd tə sɪɾ ɪn. ə lɪɾəl waɪl lɔŋɡɝ soʊkɪŋ wʊɾə bɪn wʌndɝfəl, bʌt nɑɾ ət ði ɪkspɛns ʌv weɪɾɪŋ waɪl ðə tʌbz wɝ ɛmptid bʌkət baɪ bʌkəɾ ən mɔɹ hɑt wɔɾɝ bɹɔɾ ʌp. ði ɪntaɪɝ pæləs mʌs noʊ ʃi wɑz bæk baɪ naʊ, ən ðə fɝs meɪɾ ən ðə fɝs klɝk wəd bi æŋkʃəs tə meɪk ðɛɹ deɪli ɹɪpɔɹts.

Unfortunately, the bath water had gone cold. Tepid, anyway. Hardly anything she wanted to sit in. A little while longer soaking would have been wonderful, but not at the expense of waiting while the tubs were emptied bucket by bucket and more hot water brought up.
