The entire palace must know she was back by now, and the First Maid and the First Clerk would be anxious to make their daily reports.

deɪli wən ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən dʌbli æŋkʃəs kəz ʃi hæd bɪn ɡɔn fəɹ ə deɪ. duɾi keɪm bɪfɔɹ plɛʒɝ, ɪf jə wɝ gɑnə ɹul ə kʌntʃɹi. ən ðət wɛn dʌbli fəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡeɪn ðə θɹoʊn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs.

Daily when she was in the city, and doubly anxious because she had been gone for a day. Duty came before pleasure, if you were going to rule a country. And that went doubly for trying to gain the throne in the first place.

eɪvinhə pʊl ðə taʊəl fɹəm əɹ hɛɾ ən ʃʊk daʊn əɹ hɛɹ, əpɪɹɪŋ ɹɪliv ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə klaɪm ɪndə wɔɾɝ əɡɛn. ʃi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, ʃɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊb bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ðə dɔɹ, ən hæd dɑn moʊst ə hɝ ɡɑɹməns wən ɪleɪn ən ðə meɪdz ɛntɝd. wɪð oʊnli ə fju mʌɾɝz, ʃi lɛt nɛɹɪs kəmplit ðə dʒɑb, ɔlðoʊ lɪɾəl ɹɪmeɪn bɪɑn stɛpɪŋ ɪndə hɝ hɛvi wʊlən skɝt. ʃi slæp ðə meɪdz hænz əweɪ ən taɪɾənd ðə leɪsəz ə hɝ sɑf ni-haɪ buts hɝsɛlf.

Aviendha pulled the towel from her head and shook down her hair, appearing relieved that she would not have to climb into water again. She started for the dressing room, shedding her robe before she reached the door, and had donned most of her garments when Elayne and the maids entered. With only a few mutters, she let Naris complete the job, although little remained beyond stepping into her heavy woolen skirt. She slapped the maid's hands away and tightened the laces of her soft knee-high boots herself.

fəɹ ɪleɪn, ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ izi. ənlɛs səm ɪmɝdʒənsi lumd, ɛsæn fɛl slaɪɾɪd wən ʃi dɪd nɑt dɪskʌs əɹ tʃɔɪs ə dʒɹɛsəz. wɪð kloʊs sɝvəns, ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə dɛləkət bæləns tə meɪnteɪn. wɪθaʊɾ ɪksɛpʃən ə bɑdaɪsɝvənt nu mɔɹ ə jəɹ sikɹəts ðən jə θɔt ʃi dɪd, ən ʃi sɔ jə ət jəɹ wɝst, ɡɹʌmpi, taɪɝd, wipɪŋ ɪn jəɹ pɪloʊ, ɪn ɹeɪdʒɪz ən sʌlks. ɹɪspɛk hæd tə ɡoʊ boʊθ weɪz, əɹ ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən bɪkeɪm ɪmpɑsəbəl. soʊ eɪvinhə wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə ðə pæɾəd bɛntʃɪz, əlaʊɪŋ nɛɹɪs tə koʊm aʊɾ əɹ hɛɹ, bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn kəd kənkluɾ ɑn ə sɪmpəl ɡɹeɪ ɪn faɪn wʊl, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡɹin ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk ən ðə slivz ən tʃɹɪmd wɪð blæk fɑks. ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ ðət ʃi hæd dɪfəkəlti dəsaɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðəɾ ɛsæn kɛpt pʊɾɪŋ fɔɹwɝd sɪlks soʊn wɪð pɝlz əɹ sæfaɪɝz əɹ faɪɝdʒɹɑps, itʃ mɔɹ ɔɹnətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ðən ðə læst. noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ðə θɹoʊn wɑz nɑt jɛt hɝz, ɛsænd wɑntəd tə dʒɹɛs əɹ ɛvɹi deɪ əz ə kwin ɹɛɾiɪŋ fəɹ ən ɑɾiəns. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə pɔɪn tə ðæt, bæk wən ɛvɹi deɪ bɹɔt dɛləɡeɪʃənz ə mɝtʃəns tə ɔfɝ pətɪʃənz əɹ meɪk ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛks, ɪspɛʃli aʊtləndɝz hoʊpɪŋ ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ændɝ wəd nɑɾ əfɛk ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪd. ði oʊl seɪɪŋ ðəɾ u hɛl keɪɛmlɪn hɛld ændɝ hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli bɪn tʃɹu, ən ɪn mɝtʃən aɪz, ðə tʃænsəz ʃi wəɾ æktʃəli  ɡeɪn ðə θɹoʊn hæd dɪmɪnɪʃt wɪð ði ɝaɪvəl ʌv ɛɹəmɪləz ɑɹmi aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts.

For Elayne, it was not so easy. Unless some emergency loomed, Essande felt slighted when she did not discuss her choice of dresses. With close servants, there was always a delicate balance to maintain. Without exception a bodyservant knew more of your secrets than you thought she did, and she saw you at your worst, grumpy, tired, weeping in your pillow, in rages and sulks. Respect had to go both ways, or the situation became impossible. So Aviendha was sitting on one of the padded benches, allowing Naris to comb out her hair, before Elayne could conclude on a simple gray in fine wool, embroidered in green on the high neck and the sleeves and trimmed with black fox. It was not so much that she had difficulty deciding, but that Essande kept putting forward silks sewn with pearls or sapphires or firedrops, each more ornately embroidered than the last. No matter that the throne was not yet hers, Essande wanted to dress her every day as a queen readying for an audience. There had been a point to that, back when every day brought delegations of merchants to offer petitions or make their respects, especially outlanders hoping the troubles in Andor would not affect their trade. The old saying that who held Caemlyn held Andor had never really been true, and in merchant eyes, the chances she would actually gain the throne had diminished with the arrival of Arymilla's army outside the gates.

ðeɪ kəd kaʊn ðə haʊsəz ɝeɪɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ əz izəli əz ðeɪ kəd kaʊn kɔɪn.

They could count the Houses arrayed on either side as easily as they could count coin.

ivən ændɔɝən mɝtʃəns əvɔɪɾəd ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs naʊ, kipɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl soʊ noʊ wʌn wəd θɪŋk ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn tə ðə pæləs, ən bæŋkɝz keɪm wɛl hʊɾɪd, ɪn ənɑnəməs kæɹɪdʒɪz. nʌn wɪʃt əɹ ɪl, ðət ʃi nu, ən sɝɾənli nʌn wɑntəd tə æŋɡɝ hɝ, bʌt niðɝ dɪd ðeɪ wɑnə æŋɡɝ ɛɹəmɪlə, nɑt naʊ. stɪl, ðə bæŋkɝz dɪd kʌm, ən soʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd nɑt hɝɾ ʌv ɛni mɝtʃəns pɹɪzɛntɪŋ pətɪʃənz tə ɛɹəmɪlə.

Even Andoran merchants avoided the Royal Palace now, keeping out of the Inner City as much as possible so no one would think they had gone to the palace, and bankers came well hooded, in anonymous carriages. None wished her ill, that she knew, and certainly none wanted to anger her, but neither did they want to anger Arymilla, not now. Still, the bankers did come, and so far she had not heard of any merchants presenting petitions to Arymilla.

ðət wəd bi ðə fɝst saɪn ðəɾ əɹ kɑz wɑz lɔst. ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə dʒɹɛs tʊk twaɪs əz lɔŋ əz ɪt ʃəd hæv, sɪns ɛsæn əlaʊd sɛfæni tə hɛlp ɪleɪn. ðə ɡɝl bɹið hɛvəli ðə hoʊl taɪm, ʌnəkʌstəmd əz jɛt tə dʒɹɛsɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls ən fɪɹfəl ə meɪkɪŋ ə mɪsteɪk ʌndɝ ɛsænz aɪ.

That would be the first sign that her cause was lost. Getting into the dress took twice as long as it should have, since Essande allowed Sephanie to help Elayne. The girl breathed heavily the whole time, unaccustomed as yet to dressing someone else and fearful of making a mistake under Essande's eye.

mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ə meɪkɪŋ wʌn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ mɪstʃɹəs, ɪleɪn səspɛktəd. æpɹɪhɛnʃən meɪd ðə stɝɾi jʌŋ wʊmən klʌmzi, klʌmzinəs meɪɾ əɹ mɔɹ peɪnsteɪkɪŋ, ən teɪkɪŋ peɪnz meɪɾ əɹ wɝi mɔɹ əbaʊt mɪsteɪks, soʊ ðə ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ðət ʃi muv mɔɹ sloʊli ðən ðə fɹeɪl oʊldɝ wʊmən ɛvɝ hæd.

Much more than of making one in front of her mistress, Elayne suspected. Apprehension made the sturdy young woman clumsy, clumsiness made her more painstaking, and taking pains made her worry more about mistakes, so the result was that she moved more slowly than the frail older woman ever had.

faɪnəli, haʊɛvɝ, ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf siɾəd feɪsɪŋ eɪvinhə, lɛɾɪŋ ɛsæn dʒɹɔ ən aɪvɝi koʊm θɹu hɝ kɝlz. ɪn ɛsænz vju, əlaʊɪŋ wʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz tə slɪp ə ʃɪft oʊvɝ ɪleɪnz hɛɾ əɹ fæsən əɹ bʌɾənz wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt ɹɪskɪŋ iðɝ ə ðɛm meɪkɪŋ ə tæŋɡəl ɪn əɹ hɛɹ kwaɪɾ ənʌðɝ. bɪfɔɹ ðə koʊm hæd meɪd tu dʌzən stʃɹoʊks, ðoʊ, bɝdʒɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. ɛsæn snɪft, ən ɪleɪn kəɾ ɔl bʌt si ðə wʊmən ɡɹɪmɑs bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk. ɛsæn hæd ɡɪvən weɪ ɑn bɝdʒɪt biɪŋ pɹɛzən ət bæθs, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌt ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum wɑz sækɹoʊsæŋkt.

Finally, however, Elayne found herself seated facing Aviendha, letting Essande draw an ivory comb through her curls. In Essande's view, allowing one of the girls to slip a shift over Elayne's head or fasten her buttons was one thing, but risking either of them making a tangle in her hair quite another. Before the comb had made two dozen strokes, though, Birgitte appeared in the doorway. Essande sniffed, and Elayne could all but see the woman grimace behind her back. Essande had given way on Birgitte being present at baths, however reluctantly, but the dressing room was sacrosanct.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, bɝdʒɪt lɛt ðə meɪdz dɪsəpɹuvəl slaɪd pæst wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə pleɪkeɪɾɪŋ lʊk.

Surprisingly, Birgitte let the maid's disapproval slide past without so much as a placating look.

juʒəwəli, ʃi ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm pʊʃɪŋ ɛsæn ən ɪntʃ fɝðɝ ðən ɪleɪn ɹikwaɪɝd. "daɪɛlɪn əz ɹɪtɝnd, ɪleɪn. ʃiz bɹɔt kʌmpəni. ðə haɪ sits ə mæntʃɹ, hɛvɪn, ʒəljɑɹɾ ən nɔɹθən." fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðə bɑn kæɹid stʃɹiks ə pʌzəlmən ən ənɔɪəns. ʃɛɹd hɛdeɪk əɹ noʊ, ɪleɪn cʊɾə dʒʌmp fəɹ dʒɔɪ. ɪf ɛsæn hæd nɑt hæd ðə koʊm dip ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ʃi maɪt hæv. fɔɹ! ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd daɪɛlɪn tə əkɑmplɪʃ soʊ mʌtʃ. hoʊp fəɹ ɪt, pɹeɪd fəɹ ɪt, bʌt nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt, sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪn wʌn ʃɔɹt wik. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ daɪɛlɪn wəd ɹɪtɝn ɛmpti-hændəd. fɔɹ ɡeɪv əɹ ən ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ wɪð ɛɹəmɪlə. ɪt wɑz ɡɔlɪŋ tə θɪŋk ə biɪŋ ɑn "æn ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ" wɪð ðət fulɪʃ wʊmən, bʌt tʃɹuθ wɑz tʃɹuθ. mæntʃɹ, hɛvɪn, ʒəljɑɹɾ ən nɔɹθən. waɪ nɑt kændʒɹeɪd? ðət wɑz ðə fɪfθ haʊs daɪɛlɪn hæd ɡɔn tə əpɹoʊtʃ. noʊ. ʃi hæd fɔɹ mɔɹ haʊsəz, ən ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə fɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə læk ʌv wʌn.

Usually, she refrained from pushing Essande an inch further than Elayne required. "Dyelin has returned, Elayne. She's brought company. The High Seats of Mantear, Haevin, Gilyard and Northan." For some reason, the bond carried streaks of puzzlement and annoyance. Shared headache or no, Elayne could have jumped for joy. If Essande had not had the comb deep in her hair, she might have. Four! She had never expected Dyelin to accomplish so much. Hoped for it, prayed for it, but never expected it, certainly not in one short week. In truth, she had been sure Dyelin would return empty-handed. Four gave her an equal footing with Arymilla. It was galling to think of being on "an equal footing" with that foolish woman, but truth was truth. Mantear, Haevin, Gilyard and Northan. Why not Candraed? That was the fifth House Dyelin had gone to approach. No. She had four more Houses, and she was not going to fret over the lack of one.

"ɛntɝteɪn əm ɪn ðə fɔɹməl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum əntɪl aɪ kən kʌm, bɝdʒɪt." ðə smɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum hæd bɪn səfɪʃən fəɹ zeɪɾə - ʃi hoʊp ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs hæd nɑt noʊɾəst ðə slaɪt - bʌt fɔɹ haɪ sits ɹikwaɪɝd mɔɹ. "æn æsk ðə fɝs meɪd tə ɝeɪnʒ əpɑɹtməns." əpɑɹtməns. laɪt! ði æθɑn maɪɹ wəɾ əv tə bi hɝiɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹz tə meɪk ɹum. əntɪl ðeɪ lɛft, moʊs bɛdz ðət dɪd nɑɾ əv tu ɑkjəpəns hæd θɹi. "ɛsænd, ðə ɡɹin sɪlk wɪð ðə sæfaɪɝz, aɪ θɪŋk. ən sæfaɪɝz fəɹ maɪ hɛɹ, tu.

"Entertain them in the formal sitting room until I can come, Birgitte." The small sitting room had been sufficient for Zaida - she hoped the Wavemistress had not noticed the slight - but four High Seats required more. "And ask the First Maid to arrange apartments." Apartments. Light! The Atha'an Miere would have to be hurried out of theirs to make room. Until they left, most beds that did not have two occupants had three. "Essande, the green silk with the sapphires, I think. And sapphires for my hair, too.

ðə lɑɹdʒ sæfaɪɝz."

The large sapphires."

bɝdʒɪt lɛf stɪl filɪŋ pʌzəld ən ʌpsɛt. waɪ? ʃʊɹli ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi ʃʊɾə lɛf daɪɛlɪn kulɪŋ əɹ hilz kəz ə zeɪɾə? oʊ, laɪt, naʊ ʃi wɑz filɪŋ pʌzəld oʊvɝ bɝdʒɪt filɪŋ pʌzəld; ɪf ðət wɑz əlaʊd tə fiɾ ɑn ɪtsɛlf, ðeɪ wəd boʊθ ɛn ʌp dɪzi! əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd, ɛsæn muv tə ðə nɪɹəst wɔɹdʒɹoʊb wɛɹɪŋ ə smaɪl ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn kɔl tʃɹaɪʌmfənt.

Birgitte left still feeling puzzled and upset. Why? Surely she could not think she should have left Dyelin cooling her heels because of Zaida? Oh, Light, now she was feeling puzzled over Birgitte feeling puzzled; if that was allowed to feed on itself, they would both end up dizzy! As the door closed, Essande moved to the nearest wardrobe wearing a smile that might have been called triumphant.

lʊkɪŋ əɾ eɪvinhə, hu hæd moʊʃənd nɛɹɪs ən əɹ koʊm əweɪ ən wɑz foʊldɪŋ ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ skɑɹf tə taɪ hɝ hɛɹ bæk, ɪleɪn smaɪl hɝsɛlf. ʃi niɾəd sʌmθɪŋ tə teɪk əɹ aʊɾ ə ðət spɪnɪŋ lup. "meɪbi jə ʃəd wɛɹ sɪlks ən dʒɛmz dʒʌs ðɪs wʌns mɔɹ, eɪvinhə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɛnli tizɪŋ toʊn. "daɪɛlɪn woʊn maɪnd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ði ʌðɝz ɑɹən juz tə il. ðeɪ maɪt θɪŋk aɪm ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ ə steɪbəlɪhænd."

Looking at Aviendha, who had motioned Naris and her comb away and was folding a dark gray scarf to tie her hair back, Elayne smiled herself. She needed something to take her out of that spinning loop. "Maybe you should wear silks and gems just this once more, Aviendha," she said in a gently teasing tone. "Dyelin won't mind, of course, but the others aren't used to Aiel. They might think I'm entertaining a stablehand."

ʃi mɛn ɪt fəɹ ə dʒoʊk - ðeɪ twɪɾɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ əbaʊt kloʊðz ɔl ðə taɪm, ən daɪɛlɪn lʊkt əskæns əɾ eɪvinhə wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɔɹ - bʌɾ əɹ sɪstɝ fɹaʊn ət ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz laɪnɪŋ ðə wɔl, ðən nɑɾəd ən sɛt ðə skɑɹf daʊn bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə tʌftəd kʊʃən. "dʒʌst soʊ ðiz haɪ sits wɪl bi pɹɑpɝli ɪmpɹɛst. də nɑt θɪŋk əl də ðɪs ɔl ðə taɪm. ɪts ə feɪvɝ tə ju." fəɹ sʌmwʌn dʒʌs duɪŋ ə feɪvɝ, ʃi pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə kloʊðz ðəɾ ɛsæn pʊld aʊt wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪntʃɹəs bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə dɑɹk blu vɛlvət slæʃt wɪð ɡɹin, ən ə sɪlvɝ nɛt tə kætʃ əɹ hɛɹ. ðeɪ wɝ əɹ kloʊðz, meɪd fəɹ hɝ, bʌt sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn ʃi hæɾ əvɔɪɾəd əm əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ kɹɔlɪŋ wɪð dɛθshɛd spaɪɾɝz. stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə slivz, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ɪf ʃi maɪt tʃeɪnʒ əɹ maɪnd, bʌt faɪnəli ʃi lɛt nɛɹɪs də ʌp ðə taɪni pɝl bʌɾənz.

She meant it for a joke - they twitted one another about clothes all the time, and Dyelin looked askance at Aviendha whatever she wore - but her sister frowned at the wardrobes lining the wall, then nodded and set the scarf down beside her on the tufted cushion. "Just so these High Seats will be properly impressed. Do not think I will do this all the time. It is a favor to you." For someone just doing a favor, she pored over the clothes that Essande pulled out with a great deal of interest before deciding on a dark blue velvet slashed with green, and a silver net to catch her hair. They were her clothes, made for her, but since reaching Caemlyn she had avoided them as if they were crawling with death'shead spiders. Stroking the sleeves, she hesitated as if she might change her mind, but finally she let Naris do up the tiny pearl buttons.

ʃi dɪklaɪn ɪleɪnz ɔfɝ ʌv ɛmɹəlz ðət wʊɾə suɾəd ðə ɡaʊn ædmɝəbli, kipɪŋ əɹ sɪlvɝ snoʊfleɪk nɛkləs ən hɛvi aɪvɝi bɹeɪslət, bʌɾ ət ðə læs mɪnət ʃi dɪd pɪn ði æmbɝ tɝɾəl tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ.

She declined Elayne's offer of emeralds that would have suited the gown admirably, keeping her silver snowflake necklace and heavy ivory bracelet, but at the last minute she did pin the amber turtle to her shoulder.

"ju kən nɛvɝ tɛl wən ɪt maɪt bi nidfəl," ʃi sɛd. "bɛɾɝ seɪf ðən sɑɹi," ɪleɪn əɡɹid.

"You can never tell when it might be needful," she said. "Better safe than sorry," Elayne agreed.

"ðoʊz kʌlɝz lʊk bjuɾəfəl ɑn ju." ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, bʌɾ eɪvinhə blʌʃt. kɑmpləmɛn əɹ ɑn haʊ wɛl ʃi ʃɑɾ ə baʊ əɹ haʊ fæst ʃi kəd ɹʌn, ən ʃi tʊk ɪɾ əz noʊ mɔɹ ðən əɹ du, bʌt ʃi hæd dɪfəkəlti kʌmɪŋ tə ɡɹɪps wɪð ðə fæk ðət ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl. ðət wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə hɝsɛlf ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə ɪɡnɔɹ, tɪl ɹisənli.

"Those colors look beautiful on you." It was true, but Aviendha blushed. Compliment her on how well she shot a bow or how fast she could run, and she took it as no more than her due, but she had difficulty coming to grips with the fact that she was beautiful. That was a part of herself she had managed to ignore, till recently.

ɛsænd ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn dɪsəpɹuvəl, ʌnəwɛɹ ðət ðə bɹutʃ wɑz ən æŋɡɹil. æmbɝ dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ wɪð blu vɛlvət. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz eɪvinhəz hɔɹn-hɪltɪd naɪf, wɪtʃ ʃi tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ ɡɹin vɛlvət bɛlt. ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmən meɪd ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɔɹ ə smɔl dæɡɝ wɪð sæfaɪɝz ɑn ðə skæbɝɾ ən pɑməl, hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ə bɛlt ʌv woʊvən ɡoʊld. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tə bi dʒʌst soʊ tə ɡeɪn ɛsænz æpɹəbeɪʃən.

Essande shook her head in disapproval, unaware that the brooch was an angreal. Amber did not go with blue velvet. Or maybe it was Aviendha's horn-hilted knife, which she tucked behind her green velvet belt. The white-haired woman made sure that Elayne wore a small dagger with sapphires on the scabbard and pommel, hanging from a belt of woven gold. Everything had to be just so to gain Essande's approbation.

ɹæsɔɹiə ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən eɪvinhə ɛntɝd ði æntəɹum ɪn əɹ haɪ-nɛk vɛlvəts. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ ɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ il ɡɑɹb bɪfɔɹ. eɪvinhə skaʊld əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd læft, ən ɡɹɪpt əɹ bɛl naɪf fɝmli, bʌt lʌkəli hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz daɪvɝɾɪd baɪ ə klɔθ-kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə lɔŋ saɪd teɪbəl əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ɪleɪnz mɪddeɪ mil hæd bɪn dɪlɪvɝd waɪl ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹɛsɪŋ. wɪskɪŋ ðə blu-stʃɹaɪp klɔθ əsaɪd, eɪvinhə tʃɹaɪd tə ɪntʃɹəst ɪleɪn ɪn iɾɪŋ, smaɪlɪŋ ən pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt haʊ swit ðə stu ʌv dʒɹaɪd plʌmz wəd bi ən ɪkskleɪmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə pisəz ə pɔɹk ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪni mʌʃ. slɪvɝz, ðeɪ lʊk laɪk. ɹæsɔɹiə klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən mɛnʃən ðəɾ ə faɪɝ wɑz bɝnɪŋ naɪsli ɪn ði əpɑɹtməns lɑɹdʒɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ʃi wəd bi mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə kæɹi ðə tʃɹeɪ ɪn fəɹ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn. ɛvɹiwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪleɪn eɪt pɹɑpɝli, haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ sɔ "pɹɑpɝli," bʌt ðɪs wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs. ðə tʃɹeɪ hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ səm taɪm. ðə mʌʃ wɑz ə kəndʒil mæs ðət wʊɾə stʌk ɪn ðə boʊl ɪf ʃi tɝn ɪɾ ʌpsaɪd daʊn!

Rasoria gave a start when Aviendha entered the anteroom in her high-necked velvets. The Guardswomen had never seen her in anything but Aiel garb before. Aviendha scowled as if they had laughed, and gripped her belt knife firmly, but luckily her attention was diverted by a cloth-covered tray sitting on the long side table against the wall. Elayne's midday meal had been delivered while they were dressing. Whisking the blue-striped cloth aside, Aviendha tried to interest Elayne in eating, smiling and pointing out how sweet the stew of dried plums would be and exclaiming over the pieces of pork in the grainy mush. Slivers, they looked like. Rasoria cleared her throat and mentioned that a fire was burning nicely in the apartment's larger sitting room. She would be more than happy to carry the tray in for the Lady Elayne. Everyone tried to make sure Elayne ate properly, however they saw "properly," but this was ridiculous. The tray had been sitting there some time. The mush was a congealed mass that would have stuck in the bowl if she turned it upside down!

ʃi hæd ðə haɪ sits ə fɔɹ haʊsəz weɪɾɪŋ ɑn hɝ, ən ðeɪ hæd weɪɾəd lɔŋ ɪnʌf. ʃi pɔɪntəd ðəɾ aʊt, bʌɾ ɔfɝd tə lɛt ðə tu ʌv əm iɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hʌŋɡɹi. ɪn fækt, ʃi ɪmplaɪd ðət ʃi maɪɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn əm iɾɪŋ. ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk eɪvinhə dʒɹɑp ðə klɔθ bæk oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə ʃʌɾɝ, ən ɹæsɔɹiə weɪstəd noʊ mɔɹ taɪm, iðɝ.

She had the High Seats of four Houses waiting on her, and they had waited long enough. She pointed that out, but offered to let the two of them eat if they were hungry. In fact, she implied that she might insist on them eating. That was enough to make Aviendha drop the cloth back over the tray with a shudder, and Rasoria wasted no more time, either.

ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt wɔk daʊn ði aɪsi hɔlweɪ tə ðə fɔɹməl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ən ði oʊnli θɪŋz ðət muvd, əsaɪd fɹəm ðɛm, wɝ ðə bɹaɪt wɪntɝ wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz ðət stɝɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝz dʒɹæfs, bʌt ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən fɔɹmd ə ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə ən kɛpt wɑtʃ əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd tʃɹɑləks.

It was only a short walk down the icy hallway to the formal sitting room, and the only things that moved, aside from them, were the bright winter wall hangings that stirred in the corridor's drafts, but the Guardswomen formed a ring around Elayne and Aviendha and kept watch as if they expected Trollocs.

ɪt wɑz oʊnli wɪð ən ɛfɝt ðəɾ ɪleɪn kənvɪnst ɹæsɔɹiə ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə sɝtʃ ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛntɝd. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən sɝvd əɹ ən oʊbeɪd hɝ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ wɝ plɛdʒ tə kip əɹ əlaɪv, ən ðeɪ kəd bi əz mjuli oʊvɝ ðət læs duɾi əz bɝdʒɪt wɑz oʊvɝ dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz wɔɹɾɝ, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl əɹ ɛldɝ sɪstɝ əɾ ɛni ɡɪvən moʊmənt. laɪkli, fɑloʊɪŋ ɑn ðə hilz ə ði ɪnsəɾənt wɪð zeɪɾə, ɹæsɔɹiə wʊɾə wɑntəd ðə lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz weɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd tə sɝɛndɝ ðɛɹ wɛpənz! ðə θɹɛt wɪð ðə mʌʃ maɪɾ əv hæɾ ɪts pɑɹt, tu. æftɝ ə ʃɔɹɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt, haʊɛvɝ, ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə swɛpt ɪn θɹu ðə waɪd dɔɹweɪ təɡɛðɝ, ən əloʊn. ɪleɪnz filɪŋ ə sæɾəsfækʃən dɪd nɑt læst, ðoʊ. ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɑz lɑɹdʒ, mɛn tə æksɛp dʌzənz ə pipəl kʌmfɝɾəbli, ə dɑɹk-pænəl speɪs wɪð leɪɝd kɑɹpəts kʌvɝɪŋ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ən ə hɔɹsʃu ɑɹtʃ ə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə tɔl faɪɝpleɪs ʌv waɪt mɑɹbəl wɪð faɪn ɹɛd veɪnz. hɪɹ, ɪmpɔɹɾənt dɪɡnətɛɹiz kəd bi ɹəsivd wɪð mɔɹ ɑnɝ ðən ən ɑɾiəns bɪfɔɹ ðə θɹoʊn, kəz ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ɪntəmət. ðə bleɪz dænsɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə lɔɡz ɑn ðə hɑɹθ hæd bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə teɪk ən ɛdʒ ɔf ðə tʃɪl ɪn ði ɛɹ, bʌt ðət sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt ðə ɹizən ɪleɪn fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn stʃɹʌk ɪn ðə stʌmək. ʃi ʌndɝstʊd bɝdʒɪts pʌzəlmənt, naʊ.

It was only with an effort that Elayne convinced Rasoria there was no need to search the sitting room before she entered. The Guardswomen served her and obeyed her, but they also were pledged to keep her alive, and they could be as muley over that last duty as Birgitte was over deciding whether she was Warder, Captain-General or elder sister at any given moment. Likely, following on the heels of the incident with Zaida, Rasoria would have wanted the lords and ladies waiting inside to surrender their weapons! The threat with the mush might have had its part, too. After a short argument, however, Elayne and Aviendha swept in through the wide doorway together, and alone. Elayne's feeling of satisfaction did not last, though. The sitting room was large, meant to accept dozens of people comfortably, a dark-paneled space with layered carpets covering the floor tiles and a horseshoe arch of high-back chairs in front of a tall fireplace of white marble with fine red veins. Here, important dignitaries could be received with more honor than an audience before the throne, because it was more intimate. The blaze dancing along the logs on the hearth had barely had time to take an edge off the chill in the air, but that certainly was not the reason Elayne felt as if she had been struck in the stomach. She understood Birgitte's puzzlement, now.

daɪɛlɪn tɝn fɹəm wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz ət ðə faɪɝ əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd. ə stʃɹɔŋ-feɪst wʊmən wɪð faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz ən hɪns ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, ʃi hæd nɑt weɪɾəd tə tʃeɪnʒ ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə pæləs, ən stɪl wɔɹ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ə dip ɡɹeɪ ðət ʃoʊɾ ə fju tʃɹævəl steɪnz ɑn ðə hɛm. hɝ kɝtsi wɑz ðə mɛɹəs bɛn ə hɝ nɛk, ðə slaɪɾəst dɪp ə hɝ niz, bʌt ʃi ɪntɛndəd noʊ dɪskɔɝɾɪsi. daɪɛlɪn nu hu ʃi wɑz əz ʃʊɹli əz zeɪɾə dɪd - hɝ oʊnli dʒuəlɹi wɑz ə smɔl ɡoʊldən pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə tæɹɑvɪnz aʊl ən oʊk ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ə klɪɹ stætmən ðət haɪ siɾ ə tæɹɑvɪn niɾəd nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ - jɛt ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs daɪd tə pɹuv əɹ lɔɪəlti tə ɪleɪn. "maɪ leɪɾi ɪleɪn," ʃi sɛd fɔɹməli, "ɪt ɡɪvz mi ɑnɝ tə pɹizɛn tə jə lɔɹd pɛɝaɪvəl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs mæn tɛɹ." ə pɹɪɾi, ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd bɔɪ ɪn ə pleɪn blu koʊt dʒɝkt əweɪ fɹəm piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə fɔɹ-bæɹəl kəlaɪɾəskoʊp ɑn ə ɡɪldɪd stæn tɔlɝ ðən i wɑz. hi hæɾ ə sɪlvɝ kʌp ɪn ɪz hæn ðəɾ ɪleɪn hoʊp vɛɹi mʌtʃ dɪd nɑt kənteɪn waɪn, əɹ ət list ɪkstʃɹimli wɛl wɔɾɝd ɪf ɪt dɪd. wʌn ə ðə saɪd teɪbəlz hɛl sɛvɹəl tʃɹeɪz leɪɾən wɪð pɪtʃɝz ən kʌps. ən ən ɔɹneɪt tipɑt ʃi nu maɪɾ əz wɛl bi fɪld wɪð wɔɾɝ. "maɪ plɛʒɝ, maɪ leɪɾi ɪleɪn," hi paɪpt, blʌʃɪŋ ən mænɪdʒɪŋ ə kɹɛɾəbəl baʊ dɪspaɪɾ ə lɪɾəl klʌmzinəs ɪn hænlɪŋ ðə sɔɹd bɛltəd tə hɪz weɪst. ðə wɛpən lʊk mʌtʃ tu lɔŋ fəɹ hɪm.

Dyelin turned from warming her hands at the fire as they entered. A strong-faced woman with fine lines at the corners of her eyes and hints of gray in her golden hair, she had not waited to change on reaching the palace, and still wore a riding dress of deep gray that showed a few travel stains on the hem. Her curtsy was the merest bend of her neck, the slightest dip of her knees, but she intended no discourtesy. Dyelin knew who she was as surely as Zaida did - her only jewelry was a small golden pin in the shape of Taravin's Owl and Oak on her shoulder, a clear statment that High Seat of Taravin needed nothing more - yet she had almost died to prove her loyalty to Elayne. "My Lady Elayne," she said formally, "it gives me honor to present to you Lord Perival, High Seat of House Man tear." A pretty, golden-haired boy in a plain blue coat jerked away from peering through the four-barreled kaleidoscope on a gilded stand taller than he was. He had a silver cup in his hand that Elayne hoped very much did not contain wine, or at least extremely well watered if it did. One of the side tables held several trays laden with pitchers and cups. And an ornate teapot she knew might as well be filled with water. "My pleasure, my Lady Elayne," he piped, blushing and managing a credible bow despite a little clumsiness in handling the sword belted to his waist. The weapon looked much too long for him.

"haʊs mæntʃɹ stænz wɪð haʊs tʃɹəkənd." ʃi ɹɪtɝn ɪz kɝɾəsi ɪn ə deɪz, spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ skɝts məkænɪkli.

"House Mantear stands with House Trakand." She returned his courtesy in a daze, spreading her skirts mechanically.

"leɪɾi kæɾəlɪn, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs hɛvɪn," daɪɛlɪn kəntɪnjud. "ɪleɪn," ə dɑɹk-aɪd jʌŋ wʊmən əɾ əɹ saɪd mɝmɝd, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən meɪkɪŋ ə fɹækʃənəl dɪp ðət maɪt pɑsəbli hæv bɪn ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ə kɝtsi, ðoʊ pɝhæps ʃi dʒʌs mɛn tə ɪməteɪt daɪɛlɪn. əɹ pɝhæps ʃi wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd poʊkɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn əɡɛns ðə lɑɹdʒ ɪnæməl bɹutʃ ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs, ðə blu bɛɹ ə hɛvɪn. hɝ hɛɹ wɑz kɑɾ ɪn ə sɪlvɝ nɛt wɝkt wɪð ðə blu bɛɹ, tu, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə lɔŋ ɹɪŋ wɪð ðə sɪdʒəl əz wɛl. ə tʌtʃ tu mʌtʃ pɹaɪɾ ə haʊs, pɝhæps. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ kul hɔtinəs, ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən oʊnli baɪ kɝɾəsi, hɝ tʃiks stɪl ɹaʊnd wɪð beɪbi fæt. "hɛvɪn stænz wɪð tʃɹəkənd, ɑbviəsli, əɹ aɪ wəd nɑt bi hɪɹ." daɪɛlɪnz maʊθ taɪɾənd slaɪtli, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ðə ɡɝl ə hɑɹd ɡlæns ðət kæɾəlɪn sim nɑt tə si. "lɔɹd bɹænlət, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs ʒəljɑɹd." ənʌðɝ bɔɪ, ðɪs wʌn wɪð ənɹuli blæk kɝlz, ɪn ɡɹin ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊld ɑn ðə slivz, hu heɪstəli sɛɾ ɪz waɪnkʌp daʊn ɑn ə saɪd teɪbəl əz ɪf ənizi ət biɪŋ sin wɪð ɪt. hɪz blu aɪz wɝ tu bɪɡ fəɹ ɪz feɪs, ən i nɪɹli tʃɹɪp hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪz sɔɹd, boʊɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz maɪ plɛʒɝ tə seɪ ðət haʊs ʒəljɑɹd stænz fəɹ tʃɹəkənd, leɪɾi ɪleɪn." hæfweɪ θɹu, hɪz vɔɪs bɹoʊk fɹəm tʃɹɛbəl tə bæs, ən i blʌʃt ivən hɑɹɾɝ ðən pɛɝaɪvəl.

"Lady Catalyn, High Seat of House Haevin," Dyelin continued. "Elayne," a dark-eyed young woman at her side murmured, touching her dark green divided skirts and making a fractional dip that might possibly have been intended for a curtsy, though perhaps she just meant to imitate Dyelin. Or perhaps she wanted to avoid poking her chin against the large enameled brooch on the high neck of her dress, the Blue Bear of Haevin. Her hair was caught in a silver net worked with the Blue Bear, too, and she wore a long ring with the sigil as well. A touch too much pride of House, perhaps. Despite her cool haughtiness, she was a woman only by courtesy, her cheeks still round with baby fat. "Haevin stands with Trakand, obviously, or I would not be here." Dyelin's mouth tightened slightly, and she gave the girl a hard glance that Catalyn seemed not to see. "Lord Branlet, High Seat of House Gilyard." Another boy, this one with unruly black curls, in green embroidered with gold on the sleeves, who hastily set his winecup down on a side table as if uneasy at being seen with it. His blue eyes were too big for his face, and he nearly tripped himself with his sword, bowing. "It is my pleasure to say that House Gilyard stands for Trakand, Lady Elayne." Halfway through, his voice broke from treble to bass, and he blushed even harder than Perival.

"æn lɔɹd kɑneɪl, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs nɔɹθən." kɑneɪl nɔɹθən ɡɹɪn oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ə hɪz sɪlvɝ kʌp. tɔl ən lin, ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ koʊt wɪð slivz dʒʌs tu ʃɔɹt tə kʌvɝ ɪz boʊni ɹɪsts, hi hæɾ ən ɛnɡeɪdʒɪŋ ɡɹɪn, mɛɹi bɹaʊn aɪz, ən ən iɡəlz bik fəɹ ə noʊz. "wi dʒɹu stʃɹɔz fəɹ ði ɔɹɾɝ tə bi ɪntʃɹədust, ən aɪ dʒɹu ʃɔɹt. nɔɹθən stænz wɪð tʃɹəkənd. kæn lɛɾ ə nɪni laɪk ɛɹəmɪlə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn." hi mænədʒd ɪz sɔɹd smuðli, ən i ət lis hæd ɹitʃt ɪz mədʒɔɹəɾi, bʌɾ ɪf i wɑz mɛni mʌnθs pæst sɪkstin, ɪleɪn wəɾ iɾ ɪz tɝnd-daʊn buts ən ɪz sɪlvɝ-nɑt spɝz.

"And Lord Conail, High Seat of House Northan." Conail Northan grinned over the rim of his silver cup. Tall and lean, in a gray coat with sleeves just too short to cover his bony wrists, he had an engaging grin, merry brown eyes, and an eagle's beak for a nose. "We drew straws for the order to be introduced, and I drew short. Northan stands with Trakand. Can't let a ninny like Arymilla take the throne." He managed his sword smoothly, and he at least had reached his majority, but if he was many months past sixteen, Elayne would eat his turned-down boots and his silver-knot spurs.

ðɛɹ juθ wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd kɑneɪl tə hæv ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɾ əɾ ɪz saɪd tə ædvaɪz ɪm ən ði ʌðɝz tə hæv ðɛɹ ɡɑɹɾiənz lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum əsaɪd fɹəm bɝdʒɪt, stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəd bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. bɹaɪt mɪddeɪ sʌnlaɪt flʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðə klɪɹ ɡlæs sɛɾ ɪn ðə keɪsməns meɪɾ əɹ ə sɪləwɛɾ ə dɪsplɛʒɝ. "tʃɹəkənd wɛlkəmz ɔl ə ju, ən aɪ wɛlkəm ɔl ə ju," ɪleɪn sɛd, səpɹɛsɪŋ əɹ dɪsmeɪ. "aɪ wɪl nɑt fɝɡɛt jəɹ səpɔɹt, ən tʃɹəkənd wɪl nɑt fɝɡɛt." sʌmθɪŋ ə hɝ kɑnstɝneɪʃən mʌst əv kɹɛp θɹu, kəz kæɾəlɪnz maʊθ kəmpɹɛst ən əɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd.

Their youth was no surprise, of course, but she had expected Conail to have a graying head at his side to advise him and the others to have their guardians looking over their shoulders. There was no one else in the room aside from Birgitte, standing in front of the tall arched windows with her arms folded beneath her breasts. Bright midday sunlight flooding through the clear glass set in the casements made her a silhouette of displeasure. "Trakand welcomes all of you, and I welcome all of you," Elayne said, suppressing her dismay. "I will not forget your support, and Trakand will not forget." Something of her consternation must have crept through, because Catalyn's mouth compressed and her eyes glittered.

"aɪ æm pæs maɪ ɡɑɹɾiənʃɪp, əz jə mʌs noʊ, ɪleɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə stɪf vɔɪs. "maɪ ʌŋkəl, lɔɹɾ ɝɛndɝ, sɛɾ ət ðə fist ə laɪts ðəɾ aɪ wɑz əz ɹɛɾi əz aɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ bi ən maɪɾ əz wɛl əv fɹi ɹeɪn ðən əz ɪn ə jɪɹ. tʃɹuθ, aɪ θɪŋk i wɑntəd mɔɹ taɪm tə ɡoʊ hʌntɪŋ waɪl i stɪl kæn. hiz ɔlweɪz lʌv hʌntɪŋ, ən hiz kwaɪɾ oʊld." wʌns əɡɛn ʃi feɪl tə si daɪɛlɪnz fɹaʊn. ɝɛndɝ hɛvɪn ən daɪɛlɪn wɝ ɹʌfli ʌv ən eɪdʒ.

"I am past my guardianship, as you must know, Elayne," she said in a stiff voice. "My uncle, Lord Arendor, said at the Feast of Lights that I was as ready as I would ever be and might as well have free rein then as in a year. Truth, I think he wanted more time to go hunting while he still can. He has always loved hunting, and he's quite old." Once again she failed to see Dyelin's frown. Arendor Haevin and Dyelin were roughly of an age.

"aɪ hæv noʊ ɡɑɹɾiən iðɝ," bɹænlət sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli, hɪz vɔɪs nɪɹli əz haɪ-pɪtʃt əz kæɾəlɪnz.

"I have no guardian either," Branlet said uncertainly, his voice nearly as high-pitched as Catalyn's.

daɪɛlɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə sɪmpəθɛɾɪk smaɪl ən smuðd ɪz hɛɹ bæk fɹəm ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ɪt pɹɑmpli fɛl fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn. "meɪv wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əloʊn, əz ʃi laɪk tə du, ən əɹ hɔɹs stɛpt ɪndə ə ɡoʊfɝ hoʊl," ʃi ɪkspleɪn kwaɪətli. "baɪ ðə taɪm ɛniwʌn faʊn hɝ, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. ðəɹ əz bɪn səm . . .

Dyelin gave him a sympathetic smile and smoothed his hair back from his forehead. It promptly fell forward again. "Mayv was riding alone, as she liked to do, and her horse stepped into a gopher hole," she explained quietly. "By the time anyone found her, it was too late. There has been some . . .

dɪskʌʃən . . . oʊvɝ huz tə teɪk əɹ pleɪs."

discussion . . . over who's to take her place."

"ðeɪv bɪn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ fəɹ θɹi mʌnθs," bɹænlət mʌɾɝd fəɹ ə moʊmən i lʊk jʌŋɡɝ ðən pɛɝaɪvəl, ə bɔɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɪz weɪ wɪð noʊ wʌn tə ʃoʊ hɪm ðə pæθ. "aɪm nɑt səpoʊz tə tɛl ɛniwʌn ðæt, bʌɾ aɪ kən tɛl ju. jəɹ gɑnə bi ðə kwin." daɪɛlɪn pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn pɛɝaɪvəlz ʃoʊldɝ, ən i stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ, ðoʊ hi stɪl wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ʃi. "lɔɹd wɪlɪn wəd bi hɪɹ wɪð lɔɹd pɛɝaɪvəl, bʌt ðə jɪɹz əv ɪm bɛdʒɹɪɾən. eɪdʒ kɹips ʌp ɑn əs ɔl, ɪvɛntʃəwəli." ʃi ʃɑɾ ənʌðɝ lʊk ət kæɾəlɪn, bʌt ðə ɡɝl wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ bɝdʒɪt, naʊ, hɝ lɪps pɝst. "wɪlɪn sɛɾ aɪ wɑz tə tɛl jə ðəɾ i sɛnz ɪz ɡʊd wɪʃɪz ən ɔlsoʊ wʌn i kənsɪɾɝz ə sʌn."

"They've been arguing for three months," Branlet muttered For a moment he looked younger than Perival, a boy trying to find his way with no one to show him the path. "I'm not supposed to tell anyone that, but I can tell you. You're going to be the Queen." Dyelin put a hand on Perival's shoulder, and he stood up straighter, though he still was shorter than she. "Lord Willin would be here with Lord Perival, but the years have him bedridden. Age creeps up on us all, eventually." She shot another look at Catalyn, but the girl was studying Birgitte, now, her lips pursed. "Willin said I was to tell you that he sends his good wishes and also one he considers a son."

"ʌŋkəl wɪlɪn toʊl mi tə əphoʊl ði ɑnɝ ə mæntʃɹ ən ʌv ændɝ," pɛɝaɪvəl sɛd, ɪntɛn əz oʊnli ə tʃaɪl biɪŋ sɪɹiəs kəd bi. "aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ, ɪleɪn. əl tʃɹaɪ vɛɹi hɑɹd."

"Uncle Willin told me to uphold the honor of Mantear and of Andor," Perival said, intent as only a child being serious could be. "I will try, Elayne. I will try very hard."

"aɪm ʃʊɹ jəl səksid," ɪleɪn toʊl hɪm, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə pʊɾ ət list ə lɪɾəl wɔɹmθ ɪndə hɝ toʊn. ʃi wɑntəd tə tʃeɪs əm ɔl aʊɾ ən æsk daɪɛlɪn səm vɛɹi pɔɪntəd kwɛstʃənz, bʌt ðət kəd nɑt bi, nɑt ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ eɪdʒəz, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə haɪ sits ə paʊɝfəl haʊsəz, ən ʃi hæd tə ɔfɝ ɹəfɹɛʃmən ən ət list ə mɑɾɪkəm ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɛn tə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm ðɛɹ dʒɝni.

"I'm sure you will succeed," Elayne told him, managing to put at least a little warmth into her tone. She wanted to chase them all out and ask Dyelin some very pointed questions, but that could not be, not right away. Whatever their ages, they were all the High Seats of powerful Houses, and she had to offer refreshment and at least a modicum of conversation before they went to change from their journey.

"ɪz ʃi ɹɪli ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz?" kæɾəlɪn æskt əz bɝdʒɪt hændəɾ ɪleɪn ə θɪn blu pɔɹsələn kʌp ə slaɪtli dɑɹkən hɑt wɔɾɝ. ðə ɡɝl spoʊk əz ðoʊ bɝdʒɪt wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. bɝdʒɪt ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ, bʌt kæɾəlɪn sim pɹæktəst ɪn nɑt siɪŋ wʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə si. ðə waɪnkʌp ɪn əɹ plʌmp hænd ɡeɪv ɔf ðə ʃɑɹpli swiɾ ɝoʊmə ʌv spaɪsəz.

"Is she really the Captain-General of the Queen's Guards?" Catalyn asked as Birgitte handed Elayne a thin blue porcelain cup of slightly darkened hot water. The girl spoke as though Birgitte was not there. Birgitte raised an eyebrow before leaving, but Catalyn seemed practiced in not seeing what she did not want to see. The winecup in her plump hand gave off the sharply sweet aroma of spices.

ðəɹ wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə dʒɹɑp ə hʌni ɪn ɪleɪnz mɪzɝəbəl ɪkskjus fəɹ ti.

There was not so much as a drop of honey in Elayne's miserable excuse for tea.

"jɛs, ən maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, tu," ʃi sɛd. pəlaɪtli. əz ɹɛɾi əz ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ bi! ðə ɡɝl pɹɑbli θɔɾ ɪɾ ə kɑmpləmənt. ʃi dɪzɝvd ə swɪtʃɪŋ fəɹ pjʊɹ ɹudnəs, jɛt jə kəd nɑt swɪtʃ ə haɪ sit. nɑt wən jə niɾəd əɹ səpɔɹt.

"Yes, and my Warder, too," she said. Politely. As ready as she would ever be! The girl probably thought it a compliment. She deserved a switching for pure rudeness, yet you could not switch a High Seat. Not when you needed her support.

kæɾəlɪnz aɪz flæʃt tə ɪleɪnz hænz, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə ɔltɝ ðə kulnəs ə hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən. "ðeɪ ɡeɪv jə ðæt? aɪ hæd nɑt hɝd jə hæd bɪn ɹeɪzd ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ θɔt ðə waɪt taʊɝ hæd sɛn jə hoʊm. wən jəɹ mʌðɝ daɪd. əɹ pɝhæps kəz ə ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ðə taʊɝ wi hɪɹ əbaʊt. ɪmædʒən, ɛɛs sədaɪ skwɑbəlɪŋ laɪk fɑɹmwaɪvz ət mɑɹkət. bʌt haʊ kən ʃi bi ə dʒɛnɝəl əɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə sɔɹd? ɪn ɛni keɪs, maɪ æn ɛvɛl sɛz ə wʊmən ʃəd liv sɔɹdz tə mɛn. jə doʊnt ʃu jəɹ oʊn hɔɹs wən juv ə fɛɹiɝ, əɹ ɡɹaɪn jəɹ oʊn ɡɹeɪn wən juv ə mɪlɝ." ə kwoʊt fɹəm leɪɾi ɛvɛl, noʊ daʊt. ɪleɪn skuld əɹ feɪs, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði oʊnli slaɪtli bɛɹiɾ ɪnsəls. "æn ɑɹmi ɪz ə dʒɛnɝəlz sɔɹd, kæɾəlɪn. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn sɛz ə dʒɛnɝəl u juzɪz ənʌðɝ bleɪɾ ɪz mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə dʒɑb." ðə neɪm sim tə meɪk noʊ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn hɝ, iðɝ.

Catalyn's eyes flashed to Elayne's hands, but the Great Serpent ring did nothing to alter the coolness of her expression. "They gave you that? I had not heard you had been raised Aes Sedai. I thought the White Tower had sent you home. When your mother died. Or perhaps because of the troubles in the Tower we hear about. Imagine, Aes Sedai squabbling like farmwives at market. But how can she be a general or a Warder without a sword? In any case, my aunt Evelle says a woman should leave swords to men. You don't shoe your own horse when you have a farrier, or grind your own grain when you have a miller." A quote from Lady Evelle, no doubt. Elayne schooled her face, ignoring the only slightly buried insults. "An army is a general's sword, Catalyn. Gareth Bryne says a general who uses another blade is mistaking the job." The name seemed to make no impression on her, either.

maɪnɝz' tʃɪlʒɹən ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪs nu ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪnz neɪm! eɪvinhə əpɪɹɾ əɾ ɪleɪnz saɪd, smaɪlɪŋ əz ðoʊ dɪlaɪɾəd ət ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə tɔk wɪð ðə ɡɝl. "sɔɹdz ɑɹ noʊ jus əɾ ɔl," ʃi sɛd switli. switli! eɪvinhə! ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ ɹilaɪzd əɹ sɪstɝ kəd dɪsəmbəl soʊ skɪlfəli. ʃi hæɾ ə kʌp ə mʌld waɪn, tu. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn tu mʌtʃ tə ɪkspɛkt əɹ tə kəntɪnju dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ bɪɾɝ ti aʊɾ ə sɪstɝli əfɛkʃən. "ju ʃəd lɝn ðə spɪɹ. ɔlsoʊ ðə naɪf, ən ðə baʊ. bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən kəd ʃut jəɹ aɪz aʊɾ ət tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz wɪð əɹ baʊ. meɪbi ət θɹi hʌnʒɹəd."

Miners' children in the Mountains of Mist knew Gareth Bryne's name! Aviendha appeared at Elayne's side, smiling as though delighted at the opportunity to talk with the girl. "Swords are no use at all," she said sweetly. Sweetly! Aviendha! Elayne had never realized her sister could dissemble so skillfully. She had a cup of mulled wine, too. It would have been too much to expect her to continue drinking bitter tea out of sisterly affection. "You should learn the spear. Also the knife, and the bow. Birgitte Trahelion could shoot your eyes out at two hundred paces with her bow. Maybe at three hundred."

"ðə spɪɹ?" kæɾəlɪn sɛd feɪnli. ən ðɛn, ɪn ə slaɪtli ɪnkɹɛdʒələs toʊn, "maɪ aɪz?"

"The spear?" Catalyn said faintly. And then, in a slightly incredulous tone, "My eyes?"

"ju hæv nɑt mɛt maɪ sɪstɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd. "eɪvinhə, leɪɾi kæɾəlɪn hɛvɪn. kæɾəlɪn, eɪvinhə ʌv ðə naɪn væliz tɑɹdæd." pɝhæps ʃi ʃʊɾə dʌn ðət ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd, bʌɾ eɪvinhə wɑz əɹ sɪstɝ, ən ivən ə haɪ sit mʌst sɛɾəl fəɹ biɪŋ ɪntʃɹədus tə ðə sɪstɝ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ.

"You have not met my sister," Elayne said. "Aviendha, Lady Catalyn Haevin. Catalyn, Aviendha of the Nine Valleys Taardad." Perhaps she should have done that the other way around, but Aviendha was her sister, and even a High Seat must settle for being introduced to the sister of the Daughter-Heir.

"eɪvinhə ɪz il. ʃiz stʌɾiɪŋ tə bɪkʌm ə waɪz wʌn."

"Aviendha is Aiel. She's studying to become a Wise One."

ðə ful ɡɝlz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən ət ðə stɑɹt, hɝ tʃɪn fɔlɪŋ mɔɹ ən mɔɹ wɪð itʃ pɹənaʊnsmən əntɪl ʃi wɑz ɡeɪpɪŋ laɪk ə fɪʃ. vɛɹi sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ. eɪvinhə ɡeɪv ɪleɪn ə smɔlɝ smaɪl, hɝ ɡɹin aɪz spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð æpɹəbeɪʃən əbʌv əɹ waɪnkʌp. ɪleɪn kɛpt əɹ oʊn feɪs smuð, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡɹɪn bæk.

The fool girl's mouth dropped open at the start, her chin falling more and more with each pronouncement until she was gaping like a fish. Very satisfying. Aviendha gave Elayne a smaller smile, her green eyes sparkling with approbation above her winecup. Elayne kept her own face smooth, but she wanted to grin back.

ði ʌðɝz wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ izəli hændəld, mʌtʃ lɛs ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾɪŋ. pɛɝaɪvəl ən bɹænlət wɝ ʃaɪ ðɛɹ fɝs taɪm ɪn keɪɛmlɪn mʌtʃ lɛs ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, hɑɹdli seɪɪŋ tu wɝdz ənlɛs sʌmwʌn dʒɹu ðɛm aʊt. kɑneɪl dɪd θɪŋk ðə kleɪm ðəɾ eɪvinhə wɑz il mʌs bi ə dʒoʊk, ən nɪɹli ɡɑɾ əɹ bɛl naɪf ɪn ɪz bɹɪskət fəɹ læfɪŋ ɹɔkəsli, bʌt lʌkəli, hi θɔt ðət wɑz ə dʒoʊk əz wɛl eɪvinhə ədɑptəɾ ən aɪsi kəmpoʊʒɝ ðət maɪɾ əv meɪɾ əɹ sim ə waɪz wʌn ɪn əɹ juʒəwəl kloʊðz; ɪn vɛlvəts, ʃi əpɪɹɾ ivən mɔɹ ə leɪɾi ʌv ðə kɔɹt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ʃi fɪŋɡɝɾ əɹ naɪf. ən bɹænlət dɪd kip snikɪŋ saɪɾɛlɔŋ piks ət bɝdʒɪt. ɪt tʊk ɪleɪn ə lɪɾəl waɪl tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ wɔk ɪn əɹ hil buts - ðoʊz waɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz wɝ æktʃəli  kwaɪt snʌɡ oʊvɝ ðə hɪps - bʌt ʃi oʊnli saɪd.

The others were much more easily handled, much less infuriating. Perival and Branlet were shy their first time in Caemlyn much less in the Royal Palace, hardly saying two words unless someone drew them out. Conail did think the claim that Aviendha was Aiel must be a joke, and nearly got her belt knife in his brisket for laughing raucously, but luckily, he thought that was a joke as well Aviendha adopted an icy composure that might have made her seem a Wise One in her usual clothes; in velvets, she appeared even more a lady of the court no matter how she fingered her knife. And Branlet did keep sneaking sidelong peaks at Birgitte. It took Elayne a little while to realize that he was watching her walk in her heeled boots - those wide trousers were actually quite snug over the hips - but she only sighed.

fɔɹtʃənətli, bɝdʒɪt nɛvɝ noʊɾəst, ən ðə bɑnd wʊɾə lɛɾ ɪleɪn noʊ ivən ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt.

Fortunately, Birgitte never noticed, and the bond would have let Elayne know even if she tried to hide it.

bɝdʒɪt laɪk hævɪŋ mɛn lʊk ət hɝ. ɡɹoʊn mɛn. ɪt wʊɾə dʌn ɪleɪnz kɑz noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪf əɹ wɔɹɾɝ smæk jʌŋ bɹænləts bɑɾəm.

Birgitte liked having men look at her. Grown men. It would have done Elayne's cause no good if her Warder smacked young Branlet's bottom.

meɪnli ðeɪ wɑntəd tə noʊ wɛðɝ ɹin kɔɹli wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. nʌn ə ðə fɔɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ə sɪstɝ bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðeɪ θɔt ʃi mʌs bi, sɪns ʃi kəd tʃænəl, ən kæɹi ðɛm ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn əkɹɔs hʌnʒɹədz ə maɪlz ɪn ə stɛp. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊɾ ɑpɝtunəɾi tə pɹæktəs ɪveɪʒən wɪθaʊɾ æktʃəli  laɪɪŋ, hɛlp baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ oʊn fɪŋɡɝ. ə laɪ wəd teɪn əɹ ɹileɪʃənz wɪð ðiz fɔɹ ət ðə stɑɹt, bʌɾ ɪt wəd hɑɹdli də tə hoʊp ðət ɹumɝz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪd wəd fɪltɝ aʊt tə ɛɹəmɪlə waɪl spɹɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt fɹili. ʌv kɔɹs, ɔl fɔɹ wɝ iɡɝ tə lɛɾ əɹ noʊ haʊ mɛni ɑɹmmɪn ðeɪ hæd bɹɔt, ə toʊɾəl ə dʒʌst oʊvɝ θɹi θaʊzənd, nɪɹli hæf ə ðɛm kɹɔsboʊmən əɹ hælbɝdɪɝz u wəd bi ɪspɛʃli jusfəl ɑn ðə wɔlz. ðət wɑz ə saɪzəbəl fɔɹs fəɹ fɔɹ haʊsəz tə hæv hæd ɹɛɾi tə hænd wən daɪɛlɪn keɪm kɔlɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, noʊ haʊs wɑntəɾ ɪts haɪ siɾ ənɡɑɹɾɪd ɪn ðiz taɪmz. kɪdnæpɪŋ wɑz nɑɾ ənhɝɾ ʌv wən (hi θɹoʊn sæɾ ɪn kwɛstʃən. kɑneɪl sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ, wɪð ə læf; hi sim tə faɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɝθ ə læf. bɹænlət nɑɾəd ən skɹʌbd ə hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. ɪleɪn wʌndɝd haʊ mɛni ʌv ɪz numɝəs æns, ʌŋkəlz ən kʌzənz nu hi wɑz ɡɔn, ən wʌt ðeɪ wəd də wən ðeɪ lɝnd.

Mainly they wanted to know whether Reanne Corly was an Aes Sedai. None of the four had ever seen a sister before, but they thought she must be, since she could channel, and carry them and their armsmen across hundreds of miles in a step. It was a good opportunity to practice evasion without actually lying, helped by the Great Serpent ring on her own finger. A lie would taint her relations with these four at the start, but it would hardly do to hope that rumors of Aes Sedai aid would filter out to Arymilla while spreading the truth about freely. Of course, all four were eager to let her know how many armsmen they had brought, a total of just over three thousand, nearly half of them crossbowmen or halberdiers who would be especially useful on the walls. That was a sizable force for four Houses to have had ready to hand when Dyelin came calling, but then, no House wanted its High Seat unguarded in these times. Kidnapping was not unheard of when (he throne sat in question. Conail said as much, with a laugh; he seemed to find everything worth a laugh. Branlet nodded and scrubbed a hand through his hair. Elayne wondered how many of his numerous aunts, uncles and cousins knew he was gone, and what they would do when they learned.

"ɪf daɪɛlɪn hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə weɪɾ ə fju deɪz," kæɾəlɪn sɛd, "aɪ cʊɾə bɹɔt mɔɹ ðən twɛlv hʌnʒɹəd mɛn." ðət wɑz ðə θɝd taɪm ɪn əz mɛni sɛntənsəz ðət ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə pɔɪn aʊt ðət ʃi hæd bɹɔt ðə lɑɹdʒəs kəntɪnʒənt baɪ ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl mɑɹdʒən. "aɪ hæv sɛn tə ɔl ə ðə haʊsəz plɛdʒ tə hɛvɪn."

"If Dyelin had been willing to wait a few days," Catalyn said, "I could have brought more than twelve hundred men." That was the third time in as many sentences that she had managed to point out that she had brought the largest contingent by a considerable margin. "I have sent to all of the Houses pledged to Haevin."

"æn aɪ tə ɛvɹi haʊs plɛdʒ tə nɔɹθən," kɑneɪl æɾəd. wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, ʌv kɔɹs. "nɔɹθən meɪ nɑt sʌmən əz mɛni sɔɹdz əz hɛvɪn əɹ tʃɹəkənd  -  əɹ mæntʃɹ," hi pʊɾ ɪn wɪð ə baʊ tə pɛɝaɪvəl, "bʌt huɛvɝ ɹaɪdz wən ði iɡəlz kɔl wɪl bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn." "ðeɪ wɪl nɑt ɹaɪd vɛɹi fæst ɪn wɪntɝ," pɛɝaɪvəl sɛd kwaɪətli. ən əstɑnɪʃɪŋli, sɪns noʊ wʌn hæd spoʊkən tə hɪm. "aɪ θɪŋk ðət wʌtɛvɝ wi du, wɪl əv tə də ɪt wɪð u wɪv naʊ." kɑneɪl læft ən kʌf ðə lædz ʃoʊldɝ ən toʊld ɪm tə bʌk ʌp ɪz spɪɹəts, kəz ɛvɹi mæn wɪð ə hɑɹt wɑz ɑn ɪz weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn tə səpɔɹt ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn, bʌɾ ɪleɪn stʌɾid pɛɝaɪvəl mɔɹ kloʊsli. hɪz blu aɪz mɛt hɝz fəɹ ə moʊmənt wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ʃaɪli loʊɝɾ ɪz ɡeɪz. ə bɔɪ, bʌɾ i nu wʌɾ i hæd ɹɪɾən ɪndə bɛɾɝ ðən kɑneɪl əɹ kæɾəlɪn, hu pɹəsiɾəd tə tɛl əm jɛɾ əɡɛn haʊ mɛni ɑɹmmɪn ʃi hæd bɹɔt, ən haʊ mɛni hɛvɪn kəd kɔl ɑn, əz ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn ðəɹ ɪksɛpt eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪɡzækli haʊ mɛni ɹoʊd tə itʃ haʊsəz sʌmənz, ɪn tʃɹeɪn soʊlʒɝz ən fɑɹmɝz u hæd kæɹiɾ ə hælbɹɾ əɹ paɪk ɪn səm wɔɹ ən vɪlədʒ mɛn u kəd bi dʒɹæftɪɾ ət nid. kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ɪɡzækli, ɛniweɪ. lɔɹd wɪlɪn hæd dʌn ɡʊd wɝk wɪð jʌŋ pɛɝaɪvəl. naʊ ʃi hæd tə kip ɪt fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ tə weɪst. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ kɪsəz, wɪð bɹænlət blʌʃɪŋ tə hɪz hɛɹ, ən pɛɝaɪvəl blɪŋkɪŋ bæʃfəli wən ɪleɪn bɛn tə hɪm, ən kɑneɪl vaʊɪŋ nɛvɝ tə wɑʃ ɪz tʃik. kæɾəlɪn ɹɪtɝn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli hɛzɪɾənt pɛk tə ɪleɪn 'ɛs tʃik, əz ɪf ɪt hæd dʒʌst əkɝd tə hɝ ðət ʃi hæd kənsɛntɪd tə pleɪsɪŋ ɪleɪn əbʌv hɝ, bʌɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf, kul pɹaɪd sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑn əɹ laɪk ə mæntəl. wʌns ðə fɔɹ wɝ hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə meɪdz ən sɝvɪŋ mɛn u wəd teɪk əm tə ði əpɑɹtməns ðəɾ ɪleɪn hoʊp ðə fɝs meɪd hæd hæd taɪm tə ɹɛɾi, daɪɛlɪn ɹifɪld əɹ waɪnkʌp ən sɛɾəld hɝsɛlf ɪn wʌn ə ðə tɔl, kɑɹv tʃɛɹz wɪð ə wɪɹi saɪ.

"And I to every House pledged to Northan," Conail added. With a grin, of course. "Northan may not summon as many swords as Haevin or Trakand  -  or Mantear," he put in with a bow to Perival, "but whoever rides when the Eagles call will be riding for Caemlyn." "They will not ride very fast in winter," Perival said quietly. And astonishingly, since no one had spoken to him. "I think that whatever we do, we will have to do it with who we have now." Conail laughed and cuffed the lad's shoulder and told him to buck up his spirits, because every man with a heart was on his way to Caemlyn to support the Lady Elayne, but Elayne studied Perival more closely. His blue eyes met hers for a moment without blinking before he shyly lowered his gaze. A boy, but he knew what he had ridden into better than Conail or Catalyn, who proceeded to tell them yet again how many armsmen she had brought, and how many Haevin could call on, as if everyone there except Aviendha did not know exactly how many rode to each House's summons, in trained soldiers and farmers who had carried a halberd or pike in some war and village men who could be drafted at need. Close enough to exactly, anyway. Lord Willin had done good work with young Perival. Now she had to keep it from going to waste. Eventually it was time to exchange kisses, with Branlet blushing to his hair, and Perival blinking bashfully when Elayne bent to him, and Conail vowing never to wash his cheek. Catalyn returned a surprisingly hesitant peck to Elayne 's cheek, as if it had just occurred to her that she had consented to placing Elayne above her, but after a moment she nodded to herself, cool pride settling back on her like a mantle. Once the four were handed over to the maids and serving men who would take them to the apartments that Elayne hoped the First Maid had had time to ready, Dyelin refilled her winecup and settled herself in one of the tall, carved chairs with a weary sigh.

"æz faɪn ə wiks wɝk əz aɪv ɛvɝ dʌn, ɪf aɪ də seɪ soʊ maɪsɛlf. aɪ ɡɑt kændʒɹeɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ stʃɹeɪɾ ɔf. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt deɪnin wəd bi eɪbəl tə meɪk ʌp əɹ maɪnd, ən ɪɾ oʊnli tʊk ən aʊɝ tə pɹuv mi ɹaɪt, ðoʊ aɪ hæd tə steɪ θɹi tə kip fɹəm əfɛndɪŋ hɝ. ðə wʊmən mʌs kip ɪn bɛd tɪl nun fɹəm biɪŋ əneɪbəl tə dɪsaɪd tə wɪtʃ saɪɾ ə ðə mætʃɹəs tə klaɪm daʊn fɹʌm! ðə ɹɛst wɝ ɹɛɾi tə si sɛns wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl kənvɪnsɪŋ. noʊ wʌn wɪð ɛni sɛns wɑns tə ɹɪsk ɛɹəmɪlə ɡeɪnɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn."

"As fine a week's work as I've ever done, if I do say so myself. I got Candraed out of the way straight off. I never thought Danine would be able to make up her mind, and it only took an hour to prove me right, though I had to stay three to keep from offending her. The woman must keep in bed till noon from being unable to decide to which side of the mattress to climb down from! The rest were ready to see sense with only a little convincing. No one with any sense wants to risk Arymilla gaining the throne."

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ waɪn, ðən fɪkst ɪleɪn wɪð ə stɛɾi lʊk. ʃi nɛvɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd tə spik əɹ maɪnd, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi θɔɾ ɪleɪn wəɾ əɡɹi, ən pleɪnli ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə də soʊ naʊ. "ɪt meɪ hæv bɪn ə mɪsteɪk tə pæs ðiz kɪnswɪmən ɔf əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, haʊɛvɝ saɪd-maʊðd wiv bɪn əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðə stʃɹeɪn meɪ bi tu mʌtʃ tə æsk ə ðɛm, ən ɪt pʊts əs ɔl ət ɹɪsk. ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, fəɹ noʊ ɹizən aɪ kəd meɪk aʊt, mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ən ɡeɪpɪŋ laɪk ə ɡus-ɡɝl kʌm tə ðə sɪɾi. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi ɔlmoʊs feɪld ət wivɪŋ ðə ɡeɪtweɪ tə bɹɪŋ əs hɪɹ. ðət wʊɾə bɪn wʌndɝfəl, ɛvɹiwʌn laɪn ʌp tə ɹaɪd θɹu ə mɝækjələs hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ ðət nɛvɝ mətɪɹiəlaɪzd. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðəɾ ɪt wʊɾə stʌk mi ɪn kæɾəlɪnz kʌmpəni fəɹ ðə laɪt noʊz haʊ lɔŋ. oʊɾiəs tʃaɪld!

For a moment, she frowned at her wine, then fixed Elayne with a steady look. She never hesitated to speak her mind, whether or not she thought Elayne would agree, and plainly she intended to do so now. "It may have been a mistake to pass these Kinswomen off as Aes Sedai, however side-mouthed we've been about it. The strain may be too much to ask of them, and it puts us all at risk. This morning, for no reason I could make out, Mistress Corly was staring and gaping like a goose-girl come to the city. I think she almost failed at weaving the gateway to bring us here. That would have been wonderful, everyone lined up to ride through a miraculous hole in the air that never materialized. Not to mention that it would have stuck me in Catalyn's company for the Light knows how long. Odious child!

ðɛɹz ə ɡʊd maɪn ðɛɹ, ɪf sʌmwʌn tʊk əɹ ɪn hæn fəɹ ə fju jɪɹz, bʌt ʃiz ə dʌbəl doʊs ə ðə vaɪpɝəs hɛvɪn tʌŋ."

There's a good mind there, if someone took her in hand for a few years, but she has a double dose of the viperous Haevin tongue."

ɪleɪn ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. ʃi nu haʊ kʌɾɪŋ hɛvɪnz kəd bi. ðə hoʊl fæmli tʊk, pɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪt! kæɾəlɪn ɑbviəsli dɪd. ən ʃi wɑz taɪɝɾ ʌv ɪkspleɪnɪŋ wʌɾ ɑn ðɪs deɪ kəd fɹaɪɾən ɛni wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl. ʃi wɑz taɪɝɾ ə biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəɾ ʌv wʌt ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ. ðət blʌɾi bikən wɑz stɪl bleɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə wɛst, ən ʌɾɝ ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi boʊθ fəɹ ɪts saɪz ən ɪts dʊɹeɪʃən. ðə θɪŋ hæd bɪn əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ fəɹ aʊɝz! ɛniwʌn u tʃænəl fəɹ ðɪs lɔŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹɛs mʌst əv fɔlən oʊvɝ wɪð ɪɡzɔstʃən baɪ naʊ. ən ɹænd blʌɾi ælθɹ wɑz ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ə ðæt! hi wɑz əlaɪv, bʌt ðəɾ oʊnli meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə slæp ɪz feɪs fəɹ pʊɾɪŋ əɹ θɹu ðɪs. wɛl, hɪz feɪs wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, bʌt -  bɝdʒɪt slæmd əɹ sɪlvɝ kʌp daʊn ɑn ə saɪd teɪbəl soʊ hɑɹd ðət waɪn flu ɛvɹiwɛɹ. səm lɔnʒɹɪs wɑz gɑnə swɛt tə teɪk ðət steɪn aʊɾ ə hɝ koʊtsliv. ə meɪd wəd leɪbɝ fəɹ aʊɝz tə ɹɪstɔɹ ðə saɪd teɪbəlz pɑlɪʃ. "tʃɪlʒɹən!" ʃi bɑɹkt. "pipəl ɑɹ gɑnə daɪ kəz ə ðə dɪsɪʒənz ðeɪ meɪk, ən ðəɹ fleɪmɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən, kɑneɪl wɝst ʌv ɔl! jə hɝd hɪm, daɪɛlɪn. hi wɑns tə tʃælənʒ ɛɹəmɪləz tʃæmpiən laɪk ɑɹɾɝ blʌɾi hɔkwɪŋ! hɔkwɪŋ nɛvɝ fɔɾ ɛnibəɾiz fleɪmɪŋ tʃæmpiən, ən i nu wən i wɑz jʌŋɡɝ ðən lɔɹd nɔɹθən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə fulz ɡeɪm tə ɹɛst soʊ mʌtʃ ɑn ə fleɪmɪŋ duəl, bʌt kɑneɪl θɪŋks i kən wɪn ɪleɪn ðə fleɪmɪŋ θɹoʊn wɪð ɪz fleɪmɪŋ sɔɹd!" "bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən ɪz ɹaɪt," eɪvinhə sɛd fɪɹsli. hɝ hænz wɝ fɪsts ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ skɝts.

Elayne gritted her teeth. She knew how cutting Haevins could be. The whole family took, pride in it! Catalyn obviously did. And she was tired of explaining what on this day could frighten any woman who could channel. She was tired of being reminded of what she was trying to ignore. That bloody beacon was still blazing in the west, an utter impossibility both for its size and its duration. The thing had been unchanging for hours! Anyone who channeled for this long without a rest must have fallen over with exhaustion by now. And Rand bloody al'Thor was right there, in the heart of it. She was certain of that! He was alive, but that only made her want to slap his face for putting her through this. Well, his face was not there, but -  Birgitte slammed her silver cup down on a side table so hard that wine flew everywhere. Some laundress was going to sweat to take that stain out of her coatsleeve. A maid would labor for hours to restore the side table's polish. "Children!" she barked. "People are going to die because of the decisions they make, and they're flaming children, Conail worst of all! You heard him, Dyelin. He wants to challenge Arymilla's champion like Artur bloody Hawkwing! Hawkwing never fought anybody's flaming champion, and he knew when he was younger than Lord Northan that it was a fool's game to rest so much on a flaming duel, but Conail thinks he can win Elayne the flaming throne with his flaming sword!" "Birgitte Trahelion is right," Aviendha said fiercely. Her hands were fists gripping her skirts.

"kɑneɪl nɔɹθən ɪz ə ful! bʌt haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn fɑloʊ ðoʊz tʃɪlʒɹən ɪndə ðə dæns ə spɪɹz? haʊ kəɾ ɛniwʌn æsk əm tə lid?"

"Conail Northan is a fool! But how could anyone follow those children into the dance of spears? How could anyone ask them to lead?"

daɪɛlɪn ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əm boʊθ, ən tʃoʊz tə ænsɝ eɪvinhə fɝst. ʃi wɑz pleɪnli bɪmjuz baɪ eɪvinhəz ɡɑɹb. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi wɑz bɪmjuz baɪ eɪvinhə ən ɪleɪn ədɑptɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ əz sɪstɝz, baɪ ɪleɪn hævɪŋ ən il fɹɛn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ðəɾ ɪleɪn tʃoʊz tə ɪnklud ðət fɹɛn ɪn ðɛɹ kaʊnsəlz wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʃi tɑlɝeɪɾəd. ðoʊ nɑt wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ əɹ tɑlɝeɪʃən ʃoʊ. "aɪ bɪkeɪm haɪ siɾ ə tæɹɑvɪn ət fɪftin, wən maɪ fɑðɝ daɪɾ ɪn ə skɝmɪʃ ɑn ði ɔltɑɹən mɑɹtʃɪz. maɪ tu jʌŋɡɝ bɹʌðɝz daɪd faɪɾɪŋ kæɾəl ɹeɪɾɝz aʊɾ ə mʊɹændi ðət seɪm jɪɹ. aɪ lɪsən tə ædvaɪzɝz, bʌɾ aɪ toʊl tæɹɑvɪn ɹaɪɾɝz wɛɹ tə stʃɹaɪk, ən wi tɔt ði ɔltɑɹənz ən ðə mʊɹændiənz tə lʊk ɛlswɛɹ fəɹ ðɛɹ θivɪŋ. ðə taɪmz tʃuz wən tʃɪlʒɹən mʌst ɡɹoʊ ʌp, eɪvinhə, nɑt wi, ən ɪn ðiz taɪmz, ə haɪ siɾ u ɪz ə tʃaɪl kænɑt bi ə tʃaɪld ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. "æz fəɹ ju, leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt," ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə dʒɹaɪɝ vɔɪs. "jɔɹ læŋɡwədʒ ɪz, əz ɛvɝ . . . pʌnʒənt." ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æsk haʊ bɝdʒɪt pɹəzum tə noʊ soʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, θɪŋz noʊ hɪstɔɹiən nu, bʌt ʃi stʌɾid əɹ əpɹeɪzɪŋli. "bɹænləɾ ən pɛɝaɪvəl wɪl teɪk ɡaɪɾəns fɹəm mi, ən soʊ wɪl kæɾəlɪn, aɪ θɪŋk, mʌtʃ əz aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðə taɪm əl əv tə spɛnd wɪð ðə ɡɝl. əz fəɹ kɑneɪl, hiz hɑɹdli ðə fɝs jʌŋ mæn tə θɪŋk hiz ɪnvɪnsəbəl ən ɪmɔɹɾəl.

Dyelin regarded them both, and chose to answer Aviendha first. She was plainly bemused by Aviendha's garb. But then, she was bemused by Aviendha and Elayne adopting one another as sisters, by Elayne having an Aiel friend in the first place. That Elayne chose to include that friend in their counsels was something she tolerated. Though not without letting her toleration show. "I became High Seat of Taravin at fifteen, when my father died in a skirmish on the Altaran Marches. My two younger brothers died fighting cattle raiders out of Murandy that same year. I listened to advisors, but I told Taravin riders where to strike, and we taught the Altarans and the Murandians to look elsewhere for their thieving. The times choose when children must grow up, Aviendha, not we, and in these times, a High Seat who is a child cannot be a child any longer. "As for you, Lady Birgitte," she went on in a drier voice. "Your language is, as ever . . . pungent." She did not ask how Birgitte presumed to know so much of Artur Hawkwing, things no historian knew, but she studied her appraisingly. "Branlet and Perival will take guidance from me, and so will Catalyn, I think, much as I regret the time I'll have to spend with the girl. As for Conail, he's hardly the first young man to think he's invincible and immortal.

ɪf jə kæn kip ɪm ɹeɪn ɪn əz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, aɪ sədʒɛs jə tʃɹaɪ wɔkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. ðə weɪ hi wɑz aɪɪŋ ðoʊz bɹitʃɪz ə jʊɹz, hɪl fɑloʊ ɛniwɛɹ jə lɛd." ɪleɪn . . . ʃɹʌɡd ɔf. . . ðə pjʊɹ fjʊɹi wɛlɪŋ ʌp ɪn hɝ. nɑɾ əɹ fjʊɹi, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɪt hæd bɪn əɹ æŋɡɝ ət daɪɛlɪn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, əɹ əɹ æŋɡɝ ət bɝdʒɪt splæʃɪŋ waɪn əbaʊt. ɪt wɑz bɝdʒɪts. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə slæp ɹændz feɪs. wɛl, ʃi dɪd, bʌt ðət wɑz bɪsaɪd ðə pɔɪnt. laɪt, kɑneɪl hæd bɪn lʊkɪŋ ət bɝdʒɪt, tu? "ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə haɪ sits ə ðɛɹ haʊsəz, eɪvinhə. noʊ wʌn ɪn ðɛɹ haʊsəz wəd θæŋk mi fəɹ tʃɹiɾɪŋ əm əz lɛs; fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. ðə mɛn u ɹaɪd fəɹ əm wɪl faɪt tə kip əm əlaɪv, bʌɾ ɪts pɛɝaɪvəl ən bɹænlət, kɑneɪl ən kæɾəlɪn ðeɪ ɹaɪd fɔɹ, nɑt mi. kəz ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə haɪ sits." eɪvinhə fɹaʊnd, ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz əz ðoʊ pʊlɪŋ ə ʃɔl ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, bʌt ʃi nɑɾəd. əbɹʌpli, ən ɹɪlʌktənli - noʊ wʌn ɹoʊz tə sətʃ pɹɑmənəns əmʌŋ ði il wɪθaʊt jɪɹz ʌv ɪkspɪɹiəns, ən ði əpɹuvəl ə ðə waɪz wʌnz - bʌt ʃi nɑɾəd. "bɝdʒɪt, jəl əv tə dil wɪð ðɛm, kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl tə haɪ sit. waɪt hɛɹ wʊdnt nɛsəsɛɹəli meɪk əm ɛni waɪzɝ, ən ɪt dɛfənətli wʊdn meɪk əm ɛni iziɝ tə dil wɪð. ðeɪd stɪl əv ðɛɹ oʊn əpɪnjənz, ən wɪð jɪɹz ʌv ɪkspɪɹiəns tə ɡɪv əm weɪt, moʊs laɪkli ðeɪd bi tɛn taɪmz əz sɝɾən ðeɪ nu wʌt nidz tə bi dʌn bɛɾɝ ðən jə du. əɹ ðən aɪ du." ʃi meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt tə kip əɹ toʊn klɪɹ ə ʃɑɹpnəs, ən noʊ daʊt bɝdʒɪt fɛl ði ɛfɝt. ət list, ðə floʊ ʌv ɹeɪdʒ θɹu ðə bɑn sʌɾənli dɪmɪnɪʃt. ɪt wɑz oʊnli tæmp daʊn, nɑt ɡɔn - bɝdʒɪɾ ɛndʒɔɪd hævɪŋ mɛn lʊk, ət list wən ʃi wɑntəɾ əm tə lʊk, bʌt ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ dɪd nɑt laɪk ɛniwʌn seɪɪŋ ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ətʃɹæk ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən - jɛɾ ivən soʊ, ʃi nu ðə deɪnʒɝ tə boʊθ ə ðɛm ə lɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪmoʊʃənz ɹʌn tu fɹi.

If you can't keep him reined in as Captain-General, I suggest you try walking for him. The way he was eyeing those breeches of yours, he'll follow anywhere you lead." Elayne . . . shrugged off. . . the pure fury welling up in her. Not her fury, any more than it had been her anger at Dyelin in the first place, or her anger at Birgitte splashing wine about. It was Birgitte's. She did not want to slap Rand's face. Well, she did, but that was beside the point. Light, Conail had been looking at Birgitte, too? "They are the High Seats of their Houses, Aviendha. No one in their Houses would thank me for treating them as less; far from it. The men who ride for them will fight to keep them alive, but it is Perival and Branlet, Conail and Catalyn they ride for, not me. Because they are the High Seats." Aviendha frowned, and folded her arms as though pulling a shawl around herself, but she nodded. Abruptly, and reluctantly - no one rose to such prominence among the Aiel without years of experience, and the approval of the Wise Ones - but she nodded. "Birgitte, you will have to deal with them, Captain-General to High Seat. White hair wouldn't necessarily make them any wiser, and it definitely wouldn't make them any easier to deal with. They'd still have their own opinions, and with years of experience to give them weight, most likely they'd be ten times as certain they knew what needs to be done better than you do. Or than I do." She made a great effort to keep her tone clear of sharpness, and no doubt Birgitte felt the effort. At least, the flow of rage through the bond suddenly diminished. It was only tamped down, not gone - Birgitte enjoyed having men look, at least when she wanted them to look, but she very much did not like anyone saying she was trying to attract their attention - yet even so, she knew the danger to both of them of letting their emotions run too free.

daɪɛlɪn hæd bɪɡʌn sɪpɪŋ əɾ əɹ waɪn, stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ bɝdʒɪt. oʊnli ə bɛɹ hændfʊl nu ðə tʃɹuθ ðət bɝdʒɪt dɛspɝətli wɑntəd tə kip hɪɾən, ən daɪɛlɪn wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm, jɛt bɝdʒɪt hæd bɪn kɛɹləs ɪnʌf, ə slɪp ə ðə tʌŋ hɪɹ, ə slɪp ðɛɹ, ðət ði oʊldɝ wʊmən wɑz sɝɾən ðət səm mɪstɝi hɪd bɪhaɪn bɝdʒɪts blu aɪz. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt ʃi wəd θɪŋk ɪf ʃi sɑlv ðət ɹɪɾəl. əz ɪt wɑz, ðə tu wɝ ɔɪl ən wɔɾɝ. ðeɪ kəɾ ɑɹɡju oʊvɝ wɪtʃ weɪ wɑz ʌp, ən sɝɾənli oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. ðɪs taɪm, daɪɛlɪn klɪɹli θɔt ʃi hæd wʌn, fʊɾ ən hɔɹs. "bi ðəɾ əz ɪt meɪ, daɪɛlɪn," ɪleɪn kəntɪnjud, "aɪ wʊɾə bɪn mɔɹ plizd ɪf jə hæd bɹɔt ðɛɹ ædvaɪzɝz wɪð ðɛm. wʌts dʌn ɪz dʌn, bʌt bɹænlət tʃɹʌbəlz mi ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ. ɪf ʒəljɑɹɾ əkjuzɪz mi ʌv kɪdnæpɪŋ hɪm, mæɾɝz bɪkʌm wɝs ðən ðeɪ wɝ, nɑt bɛɾɝ."

Dyelin had begun sipping at her wine, still studying Birgitte. Only a bare handful knew the truth that Birgitte desperately wanted to keep hidden, and Dyelin was not among them, yet Birgitte had been careless enough, a slip of the tongue here, a slip there, that the older woman was certain that some mystery hid behind Birgitte's blue eyes. The Light only knew what she would think if she solved that riddle. As it was, the two were oil and water. They could argue over which way was up, and certainly over everything else. This time, Dyelin clearly thought she had won, foot and horse. "Be that as it may, Dyelin," Elayne continued, "I would have been more pleased if you had brought their advisors with them. What's done is done, but Branlet troubles me in particular. If Gilyard accuses me of kidnapping him, matters become worse than they were, not better."

daɪɛlɪn weɪv ðəɾ əweɪ. "ju doʊnt noʊ ðə ɡəljɑɹdz wɛl, də ju? ðə weɪ ðeɪ skwɑbəl əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðeɪ meɪ nɑt noʊɾəs ðə bɔɪ ɪz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ sʌmɝ, ən ɪf ðeɪ du, nʌn wɪl ɹipjuɾieɪt wʌt hiz dʌn. nʌn ə ðɛm wɪl ədmɪt ðeɪ wɝ soʊ bɪzi ɪn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ huz tə bi hɪz ɡɑɹɾiən ðət ðeɪ fɝɡɑt tə kip ən aɪ ɑn hɪm. ən sɛkənd, nʌn ə ðɛm wɪl ədmɪt ðeɪ wɝn kənsʌltəd bɪfɔɹhænd. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, ʒəljɑɹd wəd stæn fəɹ zeɪɾə bɪfɔɹ stændɪŋ fəɹ mɑɹn, ən ðeɪ doʊn laɪk ɑɝɔn əɹ sɑɝən mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ."

Dyelin waved that away. "You don't know the Gilyards well, do you? The way they squabble among themselves, they may not notice the boy is gone before summer, and if they do, none will repudiate what he's done. None of them will admit they were so busy in arguing over who's to be his guardian that they forgot to keep an eye on him. And second, none of them will admit they weren't consulted beforehand. In any event, Gilyard would stand for Zaida before standing for Marne, and they don't like Arawn or Sarand much better."

"aɪ hoʊp jəɹ ɹaɪt, daɪɛlɪn, kəz aɪm əpɔɪntɪŋ jə tə dil wɪð ɛni æŋɡɹi ɡəljɑɹdz u əpɪɹ. ən waɪl jəɹ ædvaɪzɪŋ ði ʌðɝ θɹi, jə kən kip ə θʌm ɑn kɑneɪl soʊ hi dʌzn də ɛniθɪŋ kəmplitli hɛɹbɹeɪnd."

"I hope you're right, Dyelin, because I'm appointing you to deal with any angry Gilyards who appear. And while you're advising the other three, you can keep a thumb on Conail so he doesn't do anything completely harebrained."

fəɹ ɔl əɹ tɔk, ðə fɝst sədʒɛstʃən meɪd daɪɛlɪn wɪns slaɪtli. ðə sɛkən meɪɾ əɹ saɪ.

For all her talk, the first suggestion made Dyelin wince slightly. The second made her sigh.

ɪt meɪd bɝdʒɪt læf aʊt laʊd. "ɪf juv ɛni pɹɑbləmz, əl lɛn jə ə pɛɹ ə bɹitʃɪz ən səm buts, ən jə kən wɔk fəɹ hɪm."

It made Birgitte laugh out loud. "If you have any problems, I'll lend you a pair of breeches and some boots, and you can walk for him."

"sʌm wɪmən," daɪɛlɪn mɝmɝɾ ɪndə hɝ waɪn, "kæn meɪk ə fɪʃ baɪt baɪ kɹʊkɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ, leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt. ʌðɝ wɪmən əv tə dʒɹæɡ ðɛɹ beɪɾ ɔl oʊvɝ ðə pɑnd." eɪvinhə læft ət ðæt, bʌt bɝdʒɪts æŋɡɝ bɪɡæn tə ɛdʒ ʌpwɝɾ ɪn ðə bɑnd. ə weɪv ə koʊld ɛɹ swɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum əz ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən ɹæsɔɹiə ɛntɝd, kʌmɪŋ tə ə stɪf ətɛnʃən. "ðə fɝs meɪɾ ən ðə fɝs klɝk əv kʌm, maɪ leɪɾi ɪleɪn," ʃi ənaʊnst. hɝ vɔɪs fɔltɝɾ ət ði ɛnd, əz ʃi kɑt ðə muɾ ɪn ðə ɹum. ə blaɪnd ɡoʊt cʊɾə kɑɾ ɪt, wɪð daɪɛlɪn smʌɡ əz ə kæɾ ɪn ðə kɹimɝi, ən bɝdʒɪt skaʊlɪŋ əɾ əɹ ən eɪvinhə boʊθ, ən eɪvinhə tʃuzɪŋ ðɪs moʊmən tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət bɝdʒɪt wɑz bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ, wɪtʃ ɑn ðɪs əkeɪʒən meɪɾ əɹ stɛɹ ət ðə flɔɹ, əz əbæʃt əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn læfɪŋ əɾ ə waɪz wʌn. naʊ ən əɡɛn ɪleɪn wɪʃt əɹ fɹɛnz kəɾ ɔl ɡɛɾ ɑn əz wɛl əz ʃi ən eɪvinhə dɪd, bʌt sʌmhaʊ ðeɪ mænədʒ tə ɹʌb ɑn təɡɛðɝ, ən ʃi səpoʊz ðət wɑz ɹɪli ɔl ʃi kəɾ æsk fɹəm ɹil pipəl. pɝfɛkʃən wɑz ə θɪŋ fəɹ bʊks ən ɡlimənz stɔɹiz. "sɛn əm ɪn," ʃi toʊld ɹæsɔɹiə.

"Some women," Dyelin murmured into her wine, "can make a fish bite by crooking a finger, Lady Birgitte. Other women have to drag their bait all over the pond." Aviendha laughed at that, but Birgitte's anger began to edge upward in the bond. A wave of cold air swept into the room as the door opened, and Rasoria entered, coming to a stiff attention. "The First Maid and the First Clerk have come, my Lady Elayne," she announced. Her voice faltered at the end, as she caught the mood in the room. A blind goat could have caught it, with Dyelin smug as a cat in the creamery, and Birgitte scowling at her and Aviendha both, and Aviendha choosing this moment to remember that Birgitte was Birgitte Silverbow, which on this occasion made her stare at the floor, as abashed as if she had been laughing at a Wise One. Now and again Elayne wished her friends could all get on as well as she and Aviendha did, but somehow they managed to rub on together, and she supposed that was really all she could ask from real people. Perfection was a thing for books and gleemen's stories. "Send them in," she told Rasoria.

"æn doʊn dɪstɝb əs ənlɛs ðə sɪɾi ɪz ʌndɝ ətæk. ənlɛs ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt," ʃi əmɛndəd. ɪn stɔɹiz, wɪmən u ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz laɪk ðət wɝ ɔlweɪz sɛɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp fəɹ dɪzæstɝ. səmtaɪmz, ðəɹ wɝ lɛsənz ɪn stɔɹiz, ɪf jə lʊk fəɹ ðɛm.

"And don't disturb us unless the city is under attack. Unless it is important," she amended. In stories, women who gave orders like that were always setting themselves up for disaster. Sometimes, there were lessons in stories, if you looked for them.

tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin

CHAPTER 14

wʌt waɪz wʌnz noʊ ælwɪn nɔɹi, ðə fɝs klɝk, ən ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ, ðə fɝs meɪd, ɛntɝd təɡɛðɝ, hɪm meɪkɪŋ ə dʒɝki, ʌnpɹæktəs baʊ, ən əɹ ə ɡɹeɪsfəl kɝtsi ðət wɑz niðɝ tu loʊ nɔɹ tu ʃæloʊ. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ dɪfɹənt. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ wɑz ɹaʊnd-feɪst ən ɹiɡəli dɪɡnəfaɪd, hɝ hɛɹ ɪn ə nit ɡɹeɪ bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛd, mæstɝ nɔɹi tɔl ən ɡɔki əz ə weɪɾɪŋbɝd, wɪð ɪz lɪɾəl ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɛɹ stɪkɪŋ ʌp bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz laɪk spɹeɪz ʌv waɪt fɛðɝz. itʃ kæɹiɾ ən ɪmbɔs lɛðɝ foʊldɝ stʌft wɪð peɪpɝz, bʌt ʃi hɛl hɝz əɾ əɹ saɪɾ əz ɪf nɑt tə ɹʌmpəl əɹ fɔɹməl skɑɹlət tɑbɝd, ənɹɪŋkəld əz ɪɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə bi, noʊ mæɾɝ ði aʊɝ əɹ haʊ lɔŋ ʃi hæd bɪn ɑn əɹ fit, waɪl i klʌtʃt ɪz foʊldɝ tə hɪz nɛɹoʊ tʃɛst əz ɪf tə haɪɾ oʊld ɪŋksteɪnz, ʌv wɪtʃ sɛvɹəl spɑɾəd ɪz tɑbɝd, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə lɑɹdʒ blɑt ðət meɪd ðə waɪt laɪənz teɪl ɛn ɪn ə blæk tʌft. kɝɾəsiz dʌn, ðeɪ ɪmiɾiətli pʊɾ ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns bɪtwin ðɛm, itʃ nɑt kwaɪt wɑtʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝ.

What Wise Ones Know alwin Norry, the First Clerk, and Reene Harfor, the First Maid, entered together, him making a jerky, unpracticed bow, and her a graceful curtsy that was neither too low nor too shallow. They could not have been more different. Mistress Harfor was round-faced and regally dignified, her hair in a neat gray bun atop her head, Master Norry tall and gawky as a wadingbird, with his little remaining hair sticking up behind his ears like sprays of white feathers. Each carried an embossed leather folder stuffed with papers, but she held hers at her side as if not to rumple her formal scarlet tabard, unwrinkled as it always seemed to be, no matter the hour or how long she had been on her feet, while he clutched his folder to his narrow chest as if to hide old inkstains, of which several spotted his tabard, including a large blot that made the White Lion's tail end in a black tuft. Courtesies done, they immediately put a little distance between them, each not quite watching the other.

əz sun əz ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ɹæsɔɹiə, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ spɹʌŋ ʌp ɝaʊn eɪvinhə, ən ʃi woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ðət klʌŋ tə ðə wɔlz ə ðə ɹum. wʌt wɑz sɛd bɪtwin əm wɑz naʊ əz seɪf əz ðeɪ kəd meɪk ɪt, ən eɪvinhə wəd noʊ ɪf ɛniwʌn ivən tʃɹaɪd tə lɪsən wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊd wɪð ðɪs sɔɹɾ ʌv wiv.

As soon as the door closed behind Rasoria, the glow of saidar sprung up around Aviendha, and she wove a ward against eavesdropping that clung to the walls of the room. What was said between them was now as safe as they could make it, and Aviendha would know if anyone even tried to listen with the Power. She was very good with this sort of weave.

"mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɪf jəl bɪɡɪn." ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ waɪn əɹ sits, ʌv kɔɹs.

"Mistress Harfor," Elayne said, "if you will begin." She did not offer wine or seats, of course.

mæstɝ nɔɹi wʊɾə bɪn ʃɑk tə hɪz toʊneɪlz baɪ sətʃ ə læps ɪn ðə pɹəpɹaɪəɾiz, ən mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ maɪt wɛl əv bɪn əfɛndəd. əz ɪt wɑz, nɔɹi twɪtʃt ən ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət ɹɪn, ən əɹ maʊθ θɪnd. ivən æftɝ ə wiks miɾɪŋz, ðɛɹ dɪslaɪk fəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ kəd hɪɹ wɑz pælpəbəl. ðeɪ wɝ dʒɛləs ə ðɛɹ fifs, ðə mɔɹ soʊ sɪns ðə fɝs meɪd hæd muvd ɪndə tɛɹɪtɔɹi ðət wʌns maɪɾ əv bɪn kənsɪɾɝd mæstɝ nɔɹiz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ʌv kɔɹs, ɹʌnɪŋ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə fɝs meɪdz tʃɑɹdʒ, ən ɪt maɪt bi sɛd ðəɾ əɹ nu duɾiz wɝ oʊnli ən ɪkstɛnʃən ə ðæt. ɪt wəd nɑt bi sɛd baɪ hælwɪn nɔɹi, ðoʊ. ðə bleɪzɪŋ lɔɡz sɛɾəld ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, sɛndɪŋ ə ʃaʊɝ ə spɑɹks ʌp ðə tʃɪmni.

Master Norry would have been shocked to his toenails by such a lapse in the proprieties, and Mistress Harfor might well have been offended. As it was, Norry twitched and glanced sideways at Reene, and her mouth thinned. Even after a week's meetings, their dislike for giving their reports where the other could hear was palpable. They were jealous of their fiefs, the more so since the First Maid had moved into territory that once might have been considered Master Norry's responsibility. Of course, running the Royal Palace had always been the First Maid's charge, and it might be said that her new duties were only an extension of that. It would not be said by Halwin Norry, though. The blazing logs settled in the fireplace with a loud crack, sending a shower of sparks up the chimney.

"aɪ æm kənvɪns ðə sɛkən laɪbɹɛɹiən ɪz . . . ə spaɪ, maɪ leɪɾi," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd faɪnəli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ nɔɹi əz ɪf tə meɪk ɪm dɪsəpɪɹ. ʃi hæd ɹɪzɪstɪd lɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛls noʊ ðət ʃi wɑz sɝtʃɪŋ aʊt spaɪz ɪn ðə pæləs, jɛt ðə fɝs klɝk noʊɪŋ sim tə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑn əɹ wɝst ʌv ɔl. hɪz oʊnli əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ hɝ, ɪf sətʃ ɪt wɑz, keɪm fɹəm peɪɪŋ ðə pæləs əkaʊns, ən i nɛvɝ kwɛstʃən ən ɪkspɛndətʃɝ, bʌɾ ivən ðət lɪɾəl wɑz mɔɹ ðən ʃi wɪʃt. "ɛvɹi θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz mæstɝ hɑɹndɝ vɪzəts ən ɪn kɔl ðə hup ən æɹoʊ, səpoʊzədli fəɹ ði eɪl meɪd baɪ ði ɪnkipɝ, wʌn mɪlɪs fɛnʒɹi, bʌt mɪstʃɹəs fɛnʒɹi ɔlsoʊ kips pɪdʒənz, ən wɛnɛvɝ mæstɝ hɑɹndɝ vɪzəts, ʃi sɛnz ɔf ə pɪdʒən ðət flaɪz nɔɹθ. jɛstɝdeɪ, θɹi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ steɪɪŋ ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn faʊn ɹizən tə vɪzət ðə hup ən æɹoʊ, ðoʊ ɪt keɪɾɝz tə ə mʌtʃ pʊɹɝ kɹaʊd ðən ðə swɑn. ðeɪ keɪm ən wɛn hʊɾɪd, ən wɝ klɑzəɾɪd wɪð mɪstʃɹəs fɛnʒɹi ɪn pɹaɪvət fəɹ oʊvɝ ən aʊɝ. ɔl θɹi ɑɹ bɹaʊn ədʒɑ. aɪ fɪɹ ðəɾ ɪndəkeɪts mæstɝ hɑɹndɝz ɛmplɔɪɝ."

"I am convinced the Second Librarian is . . . a spy, my Lady," Mistress Harfor said finally, ignoring Norry as if to make him disappear. She had resisted letting anyone else know that she was searching out spies in the palace, yet the First Clerk knowing seemed to grate on her worst of all. His only authority over her, if such it was, came from paying the palace accounts, and he never questioned an expenditure, but even that little was more than she wished. "Every three or four days Master Harnder visits an inn called the Hoop and Arrow, supposedly for the ale made by the innkeeper, one Millis Fendry, but Mistress Fendry also keeps pigeons, and whenever Master Harnder visits, she sends off a pigeon that flies north. Yesterday, three of the Aes Sedai staying at the Silver Swan found reason to visit the Hoop and Arrow, though it caters to a much poorer crowd than the Swan. They came and went hooded, and were closeted with Mistress Fendry in private for over an hour. All three are Brown Ajah. I fear that indicates Master Harnder's employer."

"hɛɹdʒɹɛsɝz, fʊtmən, kʊks, ðə mæstɝ kæbəntmeɪkɝ, noʊ fjuɝ ðən faɪv ə mæstɝ nɔɹiz klɝks, ən naʊ wʌn ə ðə laɪbɹɛɹiənz."

"Hairdressers, footmen, cooks, the master cabinetmaker, no fewer than five of Master Norry's clerks, and now one of the librarians."

linɪŋ bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ ən kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz, daɪɛlɪn ɡlaʊɝd saʊɝli. "ɪz ðəɹ ɛniwʌn wi woʊn ɪvɛntʃəwəli lɝn ɪz ə spaɪ, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ?" nɔɹi stʃɹɛtʃt ɪz nɛk ənkʌmftəbli; hi tʊk ðə mælfizəns ə hɪz klɝks əz ə pɝsənəl əfɹʌnt. "aɪ hæv hoʊps aɪ meɪ bi ɹitʃɪŋ ðə bɑɾəm ə ðət bæɹəl, maɪ leɪɾi," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd kəmpleɪsənli. niðɝ spaɪz nɔɹ ðə haɪ sits ə paʊɝfəl haʊsəz ɹʌfəl hɝ. spaɪz wɝ pɛsts ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪd ðə pæləs ʌv əz ʃʊɹli əz ʃi kɛpt ɪt klɪɹ ə fliz ən ɹæts - ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə æksɛpt ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪd wɪð ɹæts ɹisənli - waɪl paʊɝfəl noʊbəlz wɝ laɪk ɹeɪn əɹ snoʊ, fæks ə neɪtʃɝ tə bi ɛndʒjʊɹɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɛn əweɪ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɛt flʌstɝɾ oʊvɝ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ oʊnli soʊ mɛni pipəl u kən bi bɑt, ən oʊnli soʊ mɛni kən əfɔɹd tə baɪ, əɹ wɑn tə." ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd tə pɪktʃɝ mæstɝ hɑɹndɝ, bʌɾ ɔl ʃi kəd bɹɪŋ ʌp ɪn əɹ maɪnd wɑz veɪɡ, ə tʃʌbi, bɔldɪŋ mæn u blɪŋkt ɪnsɛsənli. hi hæd sɝvd əɹ mʌðɝ, ən əz ʃi ɹɪkɔld, kwin mɔɹdʒɹɛlən bɪfɔɹ ðæt. noʊ wʌn kɑmɛntəɾ ɑn ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪt simd i ɔlsoʊ sɝv ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ.

Leaning back in her chair and crossing her legs, Dyelin glowered sourly. "Is there anyone we won't eventually learn is a spy, Mistress Harfor?" Norry stretched his neck uncomfortably; he took the malfeasance of his clerks as a personal affront. "I have hopes I may be reaching the bottom of that barrel, my Lady," Mistress Harfor said complacently. Neither spies nor the High Seats of powerful Houses ruffled her. Spies were pests she intended to rid the palace of as surely as she kept it clear of fleas and rats - though she had been forced to accept Aes Sedai aid with rats recently - while powerful nobles were like rain or snow, facts of nature to be endured until they went away, but nothing to get flustered over. "There are only so many people who can be bought, and only so many can afford to buy, or want to." Elayne tried to picture Master Harnder, but all she could bring up in her mind was vague, a chubby, balding man who blinked incessantly. He had served her mother, and as she recalled, Queen Mordrellen before that. No one commented on the fact that it seemed he also served the Brown Ajah.

ɛvɹi ɹulɝz pæləs bɪtwin ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən kənteɪn ðə taʊɝz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz. ɛni ɹulɝ wɪð hæf ə bɹeɪn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪt. daʊtləs ðə sintʃæn wəd sun bi lɪvɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝz ɡeɪz, tu, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɹɪn hæd dɪskʌvɝd sɛvɹəl spaɪz fəɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, əʃʊɹədli lɛɡəsiz ʌv ɪleɪɾəz taɪm ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt ðɪs laɪbɹɛɹiən wɑz ðə fɝs fəɹ ənʌðɝ ədʒɑ. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑɾ əv laɪkt ʌðɝ ədʒəz noʊɪŋ wʌt wɛn ɑn ɪn ðə pæləs waɪl ʃi wɑz ædvaɪzɝ tə ðə kwin.

Every ruler's palace between the Spine of the World and the Aryth Ocean contained the Tower's eyes-and-ears. Any ruler with half a brain expected it. Doubtless the Seanchan would soon be living under the White Tower's gaze, too, if they were not already. Reene had discovered several spies for the Red Ajah, assuredly legacies of Elaida's time in Caemlyn, but this librarian was the first for another Ajah. Elaida would not have liked other Ajahs knowing what went on in the palace while she was advisor to the Queen.

"ə pɪɾi wɪv noʊ fɔls stɔɹiz wi wɑn ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ tə bɪliv," ʃi sɛd laɪtli. ə ɡɹeɪt pɪɾi ðeɪ, ən ðə ɹɛdz, nu əbaʊt ðə kɪn. ət bɛst, ðeɪ hæd tə noʊ ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝ ʌv wɪmən ɪn ðə pæləs u kəd tʃænəl, ən ɪt wəd nɑt teɪk əm lɔŋ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊɾ u ðeɪ wɝ.

"A pity we have no false stories we want the Brown Ajah to believe," she said lightly. A great pity they, and the Reds, knew about the Kin. At best, they had to know there were a large number of women in the palace who could channel, and it would not take them long to figure out who they were.

ðət wəd kɹieɪɾ ɛni nʌmbɝ ə pɹɑbləmz daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, jɛt ðoʊz dɪfəkəltiz dɪd laɪ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ. ɔlweɪz plæn əhɛd, lini juz tə seɪ, bʌt wɝi tu hɑɹɾ oʊvɝ nɛks jɪɹ, ən jə kən tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ təmɑɹoʊ. "wɑtʃ mæstɝ hɑɹndɝ ən tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn aʊɾ ɪz fɹɛnz. ðət wɪl əv tə səfaɪs fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ." səm spaɪz dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ɪɹz, iðɝ tə hɪɹ ɡɑsəp əɹ lɪsən ət dɔɹz; ʌðɝz lubɹəkeɪɾɪd tʌŋz wɪð ə fju fɹɛnli kʌps ʌv waɪn. ðə fɝs pɑɹɾ ə kaʊntɝæktɪŋ ə spaɪ wɑz tə faɪn aʊt haʊ hi lɝnd wʌɾ i soʊld.

That would create any number of problems down the road, yet those difficulties did lie somewhere in the future. Always plan ahead, Lini used to say, but worry too hard over next year, and you can trip over tomorrow. "Watch Master Harnder and try to find out his friends. That will have to suffice for the time being." Some spies depended on their ears, either to hear gossip or listen at doors; others lubricated tongues with a few friendly cups of wine. The first part of counteracting a spy was to find out how he learned what he sold.

eɪvinhə snɔɹɾɪd laʊdli ænd, spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ skɝts, stɑɹɾəd tə sɪt daʊn ɑn ðə kɑɹpət bɪfɔɹ ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɔɹ. wɪð ə wɔɹnɪŋ ɡlæns ət daɪɛlɪn, ʃi pɝtʃt stɪfli ɑn ðə fɹʌn ɛdʒ ʌv ə tʃɛɹ ɪnstɛd, ðə pɪktʃɝ ʌv ə kɔɹt leɪɾi wɪð əɹ aɪz flæʃɪŋ. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ə leɪɾi ʌv ðə kɔɹt wəd nɑɾ əv tʃɛk ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ bɛl naɪf wɪð ə θʌm. lɛf tə hɝ oʊn dɪvaɪsəz, eɪvinhə wəd slɪɾ ɛvɹi spaɪz θɹoʊɾ əz sun əz ɪt kəd bi stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ ðə naɪf. spaɪɪŋ wɑz ə vaɪl bɪznəs, ɪn əɹ vju, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ɪleɪn ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ ɛvɹi spaɪ faʊnd wɑz ə tul ðət kəd bi juz tə meɪk əɹ ɛnəmiz bɪliv wʌt ʃi wɑntəd. nɑt ðəɾ ɛvɹi spaɪ nɛsəsɛɹəli wɝk fəɹ ən ɛnəmi. moʊst ə ðoʊz ðə fɝs meɪd hæɾ ənkʌvɝd tʊk mʌni fɹəm mɔɹ ðən wʌn sɔɹs, ən əmʌŋ ðoʊz ʃi hæɾ aɪdɛntəfaɪd wɝ kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən ə mʊɹændi, vɛɹiəs tɛɹən haɪ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, ə hændfʊl ə kɛɹhinɪn noʊbəlz, ən ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɝtʃəns. ə ɡʊd mɛni pipəl wɝ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌt hæpən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, wɛðɝ fəɹ ɪts ɪfɛkt ɑn tʃɹeɪɾ əɹ ʌðɝ ɹizənz. səmtaɪmz ɪt sim ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn spaɪɾ ɑn ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

Aviendha snorted loudly and, spreading her skirts, started to sit down on the carpet before realizing what she wore. With a warning glance at Dyelin, she perched stiffly on the front edge of a chair instead, the picture of a court lady with her eyes flashing. Except that a lady of the court would not have checked the edge of her belt knife with a thumb. Left to her own devices, Aviendha would slit every spy's throat as soon as it could be stretched for the knife. Spying was a vile business, in her view, no matter how often Elayne explained that every spy found was a tool that could be used to make her enemies believe what she wanted. Not that every spy necessarily worked for an enemy. Most of those the First Maid had uncovered took money from more than one source, and among those she had identified were King Roedran of Murandy, various Tairen High Lords and Ladies, a handful of Cairhienin nobles, and a fair number of merchants. A good many people were interested in what happened in Caemlyn, whether for its effect on trade or other reasons. Sometimes it seemed that everyone spied on everyone else.

"mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ," ʃi sɛd, "ju hævən faʊn ɛni aɪz-ændɪɹz fəɹ ðə blæk taʊɝ." laɪk moʊs pipəl u hɝd ðə blæk taʊɝ mɛnʃənd, daɪɛlɪn ʃɪvɝd, ən tʊk ə dip dʒɹɪŋk ə hɝ waɪn, bʌt ɹɪn dʒʌst ɡɹɪməs feɪnli. ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, sɪns ʃi kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ mæɾɝz. tə hɝ, ðə blæk taʊɝ wɑz . . . ən ənɔɪəns.

"Mistress Harfor," she said, "you haven't found any eyes-andears for the Black Tower." Like most people who heard the Black Tower mentioned, Dyelin shivered, and took a deep drink of her wine, but Reene just grimaced faintly. She had decided to ignore the fact that they were men who could channel, since she could not change matters. To her, the Black Tower was . . . an annoyance.

"ðeɪ hævən hæd taɪm, maɪ leɪɾi. ɡɪv əm ə jɪɹ, ən jəl faɪn fʊtmən ən laɪbɹɛɹiənz teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɔɪn, tu."

"They haven't had time, my Lady. Give them a year, and you'll find footmen and librarians taking their coin, too."

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ wɪl." dʒɹɛdfəl θɔt. "wʌɾ ɛls juv fəɹ əs tədeɪ?"

"I suppose I will." Dreadful thought. "What else do you have for us today?"

"aɪv hæɾ ə wɝd wɪð dʒɑn skɛlɪt, maɪ leɪɾi. ə mæn u tɝnz ɪz koʊt wʌns ɪz ɔfən əmɛnəbəl tə tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛn, ən skɛlɪɾ ɪz." skɛlɪt, ə bɑɹbɝ, wɑz ɪn ðə peɪ ʌv haʊs ɑɝɔn, wɪtʃ fəɹ ðə pɹɛzən meɪɾ ɪm ɛɹəmɪləz mæn.

"I've had a word with Jon Skellit, my Lady. A man who turns his coat once is often amenable to turning it again, and Skellit is." Skellit, a barber, was in the pay of House Arawn, which for the present made him Arymilla's man.

bɝdʒɪt bɪɾ ɔf ən oʊθ ɪn mɪdwɝd - fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə wɑtʃ əɹ læŋɡwədʒ ɝaʊn ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ - ən spoʊk ɪn ə peɪn vɔɪs.
