Given the hour, it seemed more than likely she would be spending the night here, but as yet, she had no idea where she would sleep.

daʊtləs ɪn səm lɛsɝ noʊbəlz tɛnt, wɪð ðə lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi ʃʌfəld ɔf tə faɪn heɪvən ɛlswɛɹ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt ðə bɛs feɪs ɑn biɪŋ ɪvɪktɪd, bʌɾ ɛɹəmɪlə laɪk livɪŋ əɹ ɑn tɛntɝhʊks əntɪl ðə vɛɹi læst, əbaʊt bɛdz ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. wʌn səspɛns wɑz noʊ sunɝ dɪspɛl ðən ənʌðɝ ɹipleɪst ɪt.

Doubtless in some lesser noble's tent, with the lord or lady shuffled off to find haven elsewhere and trying to put the best face on being evicted, but Arymilla liked leaving her on tenterhooks until the very last, about beds and everything else. One suspense was no sooner dispelled than another replaced it.

pleɪnli ðə wʊmən θɔt ðə kɑnstən ənsɝɾənti wəd meɪk əɹ skwɝm, pɝhæps ivən stʃɹaɪv tə pliz. ðət wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm ði oʊnli mɪskælkjəleɪʃən ɛɹəmɪlə hæd meɪd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ðə bɪlif ðəɾ ɛləniə sɑɝənz klɔz hæd bɪn klɪpt.

Plainly the woman thought the constant uncertainty would make her squirm, perhaps even strive to please. That was far from the only miscalculation Arymilla had made, beginning with the belief that Elenia Sarand's claws had been clipped.

ʃi hæd dʒʌs fɔɹ mɛn wɪð ðə tu ɡoʊldən bɔɹz ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks əz ɛskɔɹt - ən əɹ meɪd, dʒæni, ʌv kɔɹs, hʌɾəlɪŋ ɪn əɹ kloʊk tɪl ʃi simd ə bʌndəl ʌv ɡɹin wʊl paɪld ɑn əɹ sæɾəl - ən ʃi hæd nɑt sin ə sɪŋɡəl fɛloʊ mɔɹ ɪn ðə kæmp u ʃi kəd bi ʃʊɹ hɛld ə skɹæp ə lɔɪəlti tə sɑɝənd. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wʌn ə ðə klʌmps ə mɛn hʌɾəld ɝaʊn ðə kæmpfaɪɝz wɪð ðɛɹ lɔnʒɹəsəz ən simstʃɹəsəz dɪspleɪd haʊs ænʃɝz ɹɛd fɑks, ən ə dʌbəl kɑləm ə hɔɹsmən wɛɹɪŋ bɛɹɪnz wɪŋ hæmɝ pæst əɹ hɛɾɪŋ ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən əɾ ə sloʊ wɔk, hɑɹd-feɪs bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts. ðeɪ wɝ ə lɪɾəl ɹil əkaʊnt, ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn. kɑɝɪn ən lɝ hæd ɡɑɾən sɪŋʒd bædli baɪ biɪŋ sloʊ wən mɔɹɡeɪs tʊk ðə θɹoʊn. ðɪs taɪm ðeɪ wəd teɪk ænʃɝ ən bɛɹɪn wɛɹɛvɝ ði ædvæntɪdʒ leɪ ði ɪnstən ðeɪ sɔ ɪt klɪɹli, əbændənɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə wɪð əz ɡɹeɪɾ ən əlækɹəɾi əz ðeɪ hæd lɛp tə dʒɔɪn hɝ. wən ðə taɪm keɪm. moʊst ə ðə mɛn tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə mʌɾi slʌʃ əɹ piɹɪŋ hoʊpfəli ɪndə ðoʊz dɪsɡʌstɪŋ kʊkpɑts wɝ lɛviz, fɑɹmɝz ən vɪlɪdʒɝz ɡæðɝɾ ʌp wən ðɛɹ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi mɑɹtʃt, ən fju wɔɹ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə haʊs bædʒ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃæbi koʊts ən pætʃt kloʊks. ivən sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ pjuɾətɪv soʊlʒɝz fɹəm fɛɹiɝz ən flɛtʃɝz ən ðə laɪk wɑz nɪɹ ɪmpɑsəbəl, sɪns nɪɹli ɔl hæd bɛltəɾ ɑn ə sɔɹɾ ə səm dɪskɹɪpʃən, əɹ ən æks. laɪt, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðə wɪmən wɔɹ naɪvz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə bi kɔld ʃɔɹt-sɔɹdz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl səm kənskɹɪptɪd fɑɹmɝz waɪf fɹəm ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ. ðeɪ wɔɹ ðə seɪm θɪk wʊl ən hæd ðə seɪm ɹʌf hænz ən wɪɹi feɪsəz. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli mæɾɝ, ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðɪs wɪntɝ sidʒ wɑz ə daɪɹ mɪsteɪk - ði ɑɹmmɪn wəd bɪɡɪn ɡoʊɪŋ hʌŋɡɹi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə sɪɾi dɪd - bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv ɛləniə ən ɑpɝtunəɾi, ən wən ən oʊpənɪŋ pɹizɛntəɾ ɪtsɛlf, jə stʃɹʌk. kipɪŋ əɹ hʊd bæk fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ hɝ fitʃɝz klɪɹli ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə fɹizɪŋ wɪnd, ʃi nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪʃəsli tə ɛvɹi ənwɑʃt laʊɾ u soʊ mʌtʃ əz lʊkt ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən, ən ɪɡnɔɹd ðə sɝpɹaɪz stɑɹts ðət səm ɡeɪv əɾ əɹ kɑndəsɛnʃən.

She had just four men with the two Golden Boars on their cloaks as escort - and her maid, Janny, of course, huddling in her cloak till she seemed a bundle of green wool piled on her saddle - and she had not seen a single fellow more in the camp who she could be sure held a scrap of loyalty to Sarand. Here and there one of the clumps of men huddled around the campfires with their laundresses and seamstresses displayed House Anshar's Red Fox, and a double column of horsemen wearing Baryn's Winged Hammer passed her heading in the opposite direction at a slow walk, hard-faced behind the bars of their helmets. They were of little real account, in the long run. Karind and Lir had gotten singed badly by being slow when Morgase took the throne. This time they would take Anshar and Baryn wherever the advantage lay the instant they saw it clearly, abandoning Arymilla with as great an alacrity as they had leapt to join her. When the time came. Most of the men trudging through the muddy slush or peering hopefully into those disgusting cookpots were levies, farmers and villagers gathered up when their lord or lady marched, and few wore any sort of House badge on their shabby coats and patched cloaks. Even separating putative soldiers from farriers and fletchers and the like was near impossible, since nearly all had belted on a sword of some description, or an axe. Light, a fair number of the women wore knives large enough to be called short-swords, but there was no way to tell some conscripted farmer's wife from a wagon driver. They wore the same thick wool and had the same rough hands and weary faces. It did not really matter, in any case. This winter siege was a dire mistake - the armsmen would begin going hungry long before the city did - but it gave Elenia an opportunity, and when an opening presented itself, you struck. Keeping her hood back far enough to show her features clearly in spite of the freezing wind, she nodded graciously to every unwashed lout who so much as looked in her direction, and ignored the surprised starts that some gave at her condescension.

moʊst wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɹ əfəbɪlɪɾi, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ɡoʊldən bɔɹz əɹ ɛskɔɹt wɔɹ, ən noʊ ðəɾ ɛləniə sɑɝən hæd teɪkən noʊɾəs ə ðɛm. ɑn sətʃ ə faʊndeɪʃən paʊɝ wɑz bɪlt. eɪ haɪ siɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ə kwin stʊɾ ətɑp ə taʊɝ bɪlt ə pipəl. tʃɹu, ðoʊz ət ðə bɑɾəm wɝ bɹɪks ə ðə beɪsəs kleɪ, jɛɾ ɪf ðoʊz kɑmən bɹɪks kɹʌmpəld ɪn ðɛɹ səpɔɹt, ðə taʊɝ fɛl. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə əpɪɹd tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən, ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ noʊn. ɛləniə daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə spoʊk tə ɛniwʌn loʊɝ ðən ə stuɝɾ əɹ ə pɝsənəl sɝvənt. hæɾ ɪt bɪn . . . pɹuɾənt . . . ʃi hɝsɛlf wʊɾə pæst ə fju wɝdz əɾ ɛvɹi kæmpfaɪɝ, pɝhæps ɡɹæspɪŋ ə ɡɹʌbi hænd naʊ ən ðɛn, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ pipəl ʃi hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝd bɪfɔɹ əɹ ət lis dɪsəmbəlɪŋ wɛl ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪt sim ʃi dɪd. pjʊɹ ən sɪmpəl, ɛɹəmɪlə læk ðə wɪt tə bi kwin.

Most would remember her affability, remember the Golden Boars her escort wore, and know that Elenia Sarand had taken notice of them. On such a foundation power was built. A High Seat as much as a queen stood atop a tower built of people. True, those at the bottom were bricks of the basest clay, yet if those common bricks crumpled in their support, the tower fell. That was something Arymilla appeared to have forgotten, if she had ever known. Elenia doubted that Arymilla spoke to anyone lower than a steward or a personal servant. Had it been . . . prudent . . . she herself would have passed a few words at every campfire, perhaps grasping a grubby hand now and then, remembering people she had encountered before or at least dissembling well enough to make it seem she did. Pure and simple, Arymilla lacked the wit to be queen.

ðə kæmp kʌvɝd mɔɹ ɡɹaʊn ðən moʊs taʊnz, mɔɹ laɪk ə hʌnʒɹəd klʌstɝd kæmps ə vɛɹiɪŋ saɪzəz ðən wʌn, soʊ ʃi wɑz fɹi tə wɑndɝ wɪθaʊt wɝiɪŋ tu mʌtʃ əbaʊt stʃɹeɪɪŋ kloʊs tə ði aʊɾɝ baʊndɝiz, bʌt ʃi tʊk ə kɛɹ ɛniweɪ. ðə ɡɑɹdz ɑn sɛntʃɹi wəd bi pəlaɪt, ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ ʌɾɝ fulz, jɛt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt ðeɪ hæd ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝz. ɑn pɹɪnsəpəl, ʃi əpɹuvd ə pipəl duɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ toʊld, bʌɾ ɪt wəd bi bɛs tə əvɔɪɾ ɛni ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ ɪnsəɾənts. ɪspɛʃli ɡɪvən ðə laɪkli kɑnsəkwɛnsəz ɪf ɛɹəmɪlə æktʃəli  θɔt ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə liv. ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn fɔɹs tə ɛndʒjʊɹ wʌn fɹɪdʒəd naɪt slipɪŋ ɪn səm soʊlʒɝz fɪlθi tɛnt, ə ʃɛltɝ hɑɹdli wɝθ ðə neɪm, kəmplit wɪð vɝmɪn ən bædli pætʃt hoʊlz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə læk ə dʒæni tə hɛlp əɹ wɪð əɹ kloʊðz ən æɾ ə lɪɾəl wɔɹmθ ʌndɝ ðə sɑɹi ɪkskjus fəɹ blæŋkəts, ən ðət hæd bɪn fəɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə pɝsiv slaɪt. wɛl, ɪt hæd bɪn ən æktʃəwəl slaɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt θɔɾ ɛɹəmɪlə bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə kætʃ ɪt.

The camp covered more ground than most towns, more like a hundred clustered camps of varying sizes than one, so she was free to wander without worrying too much about straying close to the outer boundaries, but she took a care anyway. The guards on sentry would be polite, unless they were utter fools, yet without any doubt they had their orders. On principle, she approved of people doing as they were told, but it would be best to avoid any embarrassing incidents. Especially given the likely consequences if Arymilla actually thought she had been trying to leave. She had already been forced to endure one frigid night sleeping in some soldier's filthy tent, a shelter hardly worth the name, complete with vermin and badly patched holes, not to mention the lack of Janny to help her with her clothes and add a little warmth under the sorry excuse for blankets, and that had been for no more than a perceived slight. Well, it had been an actual slight, but she had not thought Arymilla bright enough to catch it.

laɪt, tə θɪŋk ðət ʃi mʌst stɛp wɛɹəli ɝaʊn ðət . . . ðət pi-bɹeɪnd nɪni! pʊlɪŋ əɹ kloʊk kloʊsɝ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn ðəɾ əɹ ʃʌɾɝ wɑz dʒʌst ə ɹiækʃən tə ðə wɪnd. ðəɹ wɝ bɛɾɝ θɪŋz tə dwɛl ɑn. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋz. ʃi nɑɾəd tə ə waɪd-aɪd jʌŋ mæn wɪð ə dɑɹk skɑɹf ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, ən i ɹikɔɪld əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɡlɛɹd. ful pɛzənt!

Light, to think that she must step warily around that . . . that pea-brained ninny! Pulling her cloak closer, she tried to pretend that her shudder was just a reaction to the wind. There were better things to dwell on. More important things. She nodded to a wide-eyed young man with a dark scarf wrapped around his head, and he recoiled as though she had glared. Fool peasant!

ɪt wɑz ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ tə θɪŋk ðæt, oʊnli ə fju maɪlz əweɪ, ðət jʌŋ tʃɪɾ ɪleɪn sæt snʌɡ ən wɔɹm ɪn ðə kʌmfɝɾ ə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, ətɛndəd baɪ skɔɹz ʌv wɛl-tʃɹeɪn sɝvəns ən laɪkli wɪθaʊt tu θɔts ɪn əɹ hɛd bɪɑnd wʌt tə wɛɹ tənaɪɾ əɾ ə sʌpɝ pɹipɛɹd baɪ ðə pæləs kʊks. ɹumɝ hæd ðə ɡɝl wɪð tʃaɪld, pɑsəbli baɪ səm ɡɑɹdzmæn. ɪt maɪt bi soʊ. ɪleɪn hæd nɛvɝ pəzɛst ɛni mɔɹ sɛns ə disənsi ðən əɹ mʌðɝ. daɪɛlɪn wɑz ðə bɹeɪn ðɛɹ, ə ʃɑɹp maɪn ən deɪnʒɝəs nɑtwɪθstændɪŋ əɹ pəθɛɾɪk læk ʌv æmbɪʃən, pɝhæps ædvaɪz baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ mʌs bi ət list wʌn ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ əmʌŋ ɔl ðoʊz əbsɝd ɹumɝz. soʊ mɛni fæbjəleɪʃənz dʒɹɪftəɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ðət tɛlɪŋ ɹiæləɾi fɹəm nɑnsɛns bɪkeɪm dɪfəkəlt - si foʊk meɪkɪŋ hoʊlz ɪn ði ɛɹ? æbsəlut dʒɹɪvəl! - jɛt ðə waɪt taʊɝ klɪɹli hæɾ ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn pʊɾɪŋ wʌn ʌv ɪts oʊn ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. haʊ kəɾ ɪt nɑt? ivən soʊ, tɑɹ vəlɑn sim tə bi pɹæɡmæɾɪk wən ɪt keɪm tə ðiz mæɾɝz. hɪstɝi klɪɹli ʃoʊd ðət huɛvɝ ɹitʃt ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wəd sun faɪn ðət ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn ðə taʊɝ æktʃəli  hæd feɪvɝɾ ɔl əlɔŋ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt luz ðɛɹ kənɛkʃən tə ændɝ θɹu ə læk ə nɪmblnəs, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt wɪð ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf ɹɪvən. ɛləniə wɑz əz sɝɾən ə ðəɾ əz ʃi wɑz ə hɝ oʊn neɪm. ɪn fækt, ɪf hæf wʌt ʃi hɝɾ ə ðə taʊɝz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɑz tʃɹu, ðə nɛks kwin ʌv ændɝ maɪt faɪn hɝsɛlf eɪbəl tə dɪmænd wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ kipɪŋ ðət kənɛkʃən ɪntækt. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, noʊ wʌn gɑnə tə ɹɛs ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ɑn əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ sʌmɝ ət ði ɝliəst, ən ə ɡɹeɪt dil kəd tʃeɪnʒ bɪfɔɹ ðɛn. ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt dil.

It was grating to think that, only a few miles away, that young chit Elayne sat snug and warm in the comfort of the Royal Palace, attended by scores of well-trained servants and likely without two thoughts in her head beyond what to wear tonight at a supper prepared by the palace cooks. Rumor had the girl with child, possibly by some Guardsman. It might be so. Elayne had never possessed any more sense of decency than her mother. Dyelin was the brain there, a sharp mind and dangerous notwithstanding her pathetic lack of ambition, perhaps advised by an Aes Sedai. There must be at least one real Aes Sedai among all those absurd rumors. So many fabulations drifted out of the city that telling reality from nonsense became difficult - Sea Folk making holes in the air? Absolute drivel! - yet the White Tower clearly had an interest in putting one of its own on the throne. How could it not? Even so, Tar Valon seemed to be pragmatic when it came to these matters. History clearly showed that whoever reached the Lion Throne would soon find that she was the one the Tower actually had favored all along. The Aes Sedai would not lose their connection to Andor through a lack of nimbleness, particularly not with the Tower itself riven. Elenia was as certain of that as she was of her own name. In fact, if half what she heard of the Tower's situation was true, the next Queen of Andor might find herself able to demand whatever she wanted in return for keeping that connection intact. In any event, no one was going to rest the Rose Crown on her head before summer at the earliest, and a great deal could change before then. A very great deal.

ʃi wɑz meɪkɪŋ əɹ sɛkən ɹaʊn ə ðə kæmp wən ðə saɪɾ ʌv ənʌðɝ smɔl maʊntəd pɑɹɾi əhɛɾ ə hɝ, pɪkɪŋ ɪts sloʊ weɪ bɪtwin ðə skæɾɝd kæmpfaɪɝz ɪn ðə læs laɪt, meɪɾ əɹ skaʊl ən dʒɹɔ ɹeɪn ʃɑɹpli. ðə wɪmən wɝ kloʊkt ən dipli hʊɾɪd, wʌn ɪn stʃɹɔŋ blu sɪlk laɪnd wɪð blæk fɝ, ði ʌðɝ ɪn pleɪn ɡɹeɪ wʊl, bʌt ðə sɪlvɝ tʃɹɪpəl kiz wɝk lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə fɔɹ ɑɹmmɪnz kloʊks neɪmd əm klɪɹli ɪnʌf. ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɛni nʌmbɝ ə pipəl ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ ɪnkaʊntɝ ðən nɑiən ɑɝɔn. ɪn ɛni keɪs, waɪl ɛɹəmɪlə hæd nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli fɔɹbɪɾən əm tə mit wɪθaʊɾ əɹ -  ɛləniə hɝɾ əɹ tiθ ɡɹaɪn əz mʌtʃ əz fɛl ðɛm, ən fɔɹst əɹ feɪs smuð - fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɪt simd waɪzəs nɑt tə pɹɛs mæɾɝz. ɪspɛʃli wən ðəɹ sim noʊ pɑsəbəl ædvæntɪdʒ tə sətʃ ə miɾɪŋ.

She was making her second round of the camp when the sight of another small mounted party ahead of her, picking its slow way between the scattered campfires in the last light, made her scowl and draw rein sharply. The women were cloaked and deeply hooded, one in strong blue silk lined with black fur, the other in plain gray wool, but the silver Triple Keys worked large on the four armsmen's cloaks named them clearly enough. She could think of any number of people she would rather encounter than Naean Arawn. In any case, while Arymilla had not precisely forbidden them to meet without her -  Elenia heard her teeth grind as much as felt them, and forced her face smooth - for the moment, it seemed wisest not to press matters. Especially when there seemed no possible advantage to such a meeting.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, nɑiən sɔ hɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd tɝn əsaɪd. ðə wʊmən spoʊk heɪstəli tə hɝ ɛskɔɹɾ ænd, waɪl ɑɹmmɪn ən meɪd wɝ stɪl boʊɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, spɝd təwɔɹɾ ɛləniə əɾ ə peɪs ðət sɛn klɑdz ə slʌʃ flaɪɪŋ fɹəm əɹ blæk ɡɛldɪŋz hʊvz. ðə laɪt bɝn ðə ful! ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɡoʊɾɪŋ nɑiən tə ɹɛkləsnəs maɪt bi væljəbəl tə noʊ, ən deɪnʒɝəs nɑt tə. ɪt maɪt, bʌt faɪndɪŋ aʊt pɹizɛntəɾ ɪts oʊn deɪnʒɝz. "steɪ hɪɹ ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət juv sin nʌθɪŋ," ɛləniə snæpt əɾ əɹ oʊn miɡɝ ɹɛɾənu ən dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪndə dɔn wɪnz flæŋks wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛni ɹɪplaɪ. ʃi hæd noʊ nid fəɹ ɪlæbɹət baʊz ən kɝɾəsiz ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi tɝn ɝaʊnd, nɑt bɪɑnd wʌt simlaɪnəs dɪmændəd, ən əɹ pipəl nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə də ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən wʌt ʃi kəmændəd.

Unfortunately, Naean saw her before she could turn aside. The woman spoke hastily to her escort and, while armsmen and maid were still bowing in their saddles, spurred toward Elenia at a pace that sent clods of slush flying from her black gelding's hooves. The Light burn the fool! On the other hand, whatever was goading Naean to recklessness might be valuable to know, and dangerous not to. It might, but finding out presented its own dangers. "Stay here and remember that you've seen nothing," Elenia snapped at her own meager retinue and dug her heels into Dawn Wind's flanks without waiting for any reply. She had no need for elaborate bows and courtesies every time she turned around, not beyond what seemliness demanded, and her people knew better than to do anything other than what she commanded.

ɪt wɑz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ʃi hæd tə wɝi əbaʊt, bɝn əm ɔl! əz ðə lɔŋ-lɛɡəd beɪ spɹæŋ fɔɹwɝd, ʃi lɔst əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ kloʊk, ən ɪt stʃɹim bɪhaɪn əɹ laɪk ðə kɹɪmzən bænɝ ə sɑɝənd. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ɡæðɝ ðə kloʊk ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl, fleɪlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə fɑɹmɝz ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu hu, soʊ ðə wɪn ɹeɪzɝd θɹu hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ənʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ ɪɹɪteɪʃən.

It was everyone else she had to worry about, burn them all! As the long-legged bay sprang forward, she lost her grip on her cloak, and it streamed behind her like the crimson banner of Sarand. She refused to gather the cloak under control, flailing around in front of farmers and the Light alone knew who, so the wind razored through her riding dress, another reason for irritation.

nɑiən ət lis hæd ðə sɛns tə sloʊ ən miɾ əɹ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ, bɪsaɪɾ ə pɛɹ ə hɛvəli leɪɾən kɑɹts wɪð ðɛɹ ɛmpti ʃæfs laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌk. ðə nɪɹəs faɪɝ wɑz ɔlmoʊs twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ, ən ðə nɪɹəs tɛns fɑɹðɝ, ðɛɹ ɛntʃɹi flæps leɪs taɪɾ əɡɛns ðə koʊld. ðə mɛn ət ðə faɪɝ wɝ ɪntɛn ɑn ðə bɪɡ aɪɝn pɑt stimɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz, ən ɪf ðə stɛntʃ fɹəm ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛləniə wɑnə ɛmpti hɝ stʌmək, ət lis ðə wɪn ðət kæɹid ðə stɪŋk wəd kip stʃɹeɪ wɝdz fɹəm ðɛɹ ɪɹz. bʌt ðeɪ hæd bɛɾɝ bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt wɝdz.

Naean at least had the sense to slow and meet her little more than halfway, beside a pair of heavily laden carts with their empty shafts lying in the muck. The nearest fire was almost twenty paces away, and the nearest tents farther, their entry flaps laced tight against the cold. The men at the fire were intent on the big iron pot steaming over the flames, and if the stench from it was enough to make Elenia want to empty her stomach, at least the wind that carried the stink would keep stray words from their ears. But they had better be important words.

wɪð ə feɪs əz peɪl əz aɪvɝi ɪn ɪts fɹeɪm ə blæk fɝ, nɑiən maɪɾ əv bɪn kɔl bjuɾəfəl baɪ səm dɪspaɪt mɔɹ ðən ə hɪn ə hɑɹʃnəs ɝaʊn əɹ maʊθ ən aɪz əz koʊld əz blu aɪs. stʃɹeɪtbækt ən aʊtwɝdli kwaɪt kɑm, ʃi simd əntʌtʃt baɪ ɪvɛns. hɝ bɹɛθ, meɪkɪŋ ə waɪt mɪst, wɑz stɛɾi ən ivən. "du jə noʊ wɛɹ wəɹ slipɪŋ tənaɪt, ɛləniə?" ʃi sɛd kuli.

With a face as pale as ivory in its frame of black fur, Naean might have been called beautiful by some despite more than a hint of harshness around her mouth and eyes as cold as blue ice. Straightbacked and outwardly quite calm, she seemed untouched by events. Her breath, making a white mist, was steady and even. "Do you know where we are sleeping tonight, Elenia?" she said coolly.

ɛləniə meɪd noʊ ɛfɝɾ əɾ ɔl tə stɑp fɹəm ɡlɛɹɪŋ. "ɪz ðət wʌt jə wɑnt?" ɹɪskɪŋ ɛɹəmɪləz dɪsplɛʒɝ fəɹ ə bɹeɪnləs kwɛstʃən!

Elenia made no effort at all to stop from glaring. "Is that what you want?" Risking Arymilla's displeasure for a brainless question!

ðə θɔɾ ə ɹɪskɪŋ ɛɹəmɪləz dɪsplɛʒɝ, ðə θɔt ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪləz dɪsplɛʒɝ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʃi niɾəd tə əvɔɪd, meɪɾ əɹ snɑɹl. "ju noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ, nɑiən." tʌɡɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz, ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi tɝnɪŋ əɹ maʊn əweɪ wən nɑiən spoʊk əɡɛn, wɪð dʒʌst ə hɪn ə hit.

The thought of risking Arymilla's displeasure, the thought that Arymilla's displeasure was something she needed to avoid, made her snarl. "You know as much as I, Naean." Tugging at her reins, she was already turning her mount away when Naean spoke again, with just a hint of heat.

"doʊn pleɪ ðə sɪmpəltən wɪð mi, ɛləniə. ən doʊn tɛl mi jə ɑɹən əz ɹɛɾi əz aɪm tə tʃu ɔf jəɹ oʊn fʊt tə ɪskeɪp ðɪs tʃɹæp. naʊ, kən wi ət lis pɹitɛn tə səvɪləɾi?" ɛləniə kɛp dɔn wɪn hæf tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ən lʊkt əɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, pæs ðə fɝ-tʃɹɪmd ɛdʒ ə hɝ hʊd. ðət weɪ, ʃi kəd kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə mɛn kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə nɪɹəs faɪɝ, tu. noʊ haʊs bædʒɪz dɪspleɪd ðɛɹ. ðeɪ kəd bɪlɔŋ tə ɛniwʌn. naʊ ən ðən wʌn fɛloʊ əɹ ənʌðɝ ʃildɪŋ bɛɹ hænz ɪn ɪz ɑɹmpɪts ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə tu leɪɾiz ɑn hɔɹsbæk, bʌt ðɛɹ ɹil ɪntʃɹəst wɑz ɑn ʃʌflɪŋ nɪɹ ɪnʌf ðə faɪɝ tə ɡɛt wɔɹm. ðæt, ən haʊ lɔŋ ɪt wɑz gɑnə teɪk fəɹ ðə bif tə bɔɪl daʊn tə sʌmθɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ mʌʃ. ðət sɔɹt simd eɪbəl tə iɾ ɛniθɪŋ.

"Don't play the simpleton with me, Elenia. And don't tell me you aren't as ready as I am to chew off your own foot to escape this trap. Now, can we at least pretend to civility?" Elenia kept Dawn Wind half turned away from the other woman and looked at her sideways, past the fur-trimmed edge of her hood. That way, she could keep an eye on the men crowding around the nearest fire, too. No House badges displayed there. They could belong to anyone. Now and then one fellow or another shielding bare hands in his armpits glanced toward the two ladies on horseback, but their real interest was on shuffling near enough the fire to get warm. That, and how long it was going to take for the beef to boil down to something approaching mush. That sort seemed able to eat anything.

"du jə θɪŋk jə kən ɪskeɪp?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli. səvɪləɾi wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, bʌt nɑɾ ət ði ɪkspɛns ə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ hɪɹ fəɹ ɔl tə si ɛni lɔŋɡɝ ðən æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi. ɪf nɑiən sɔ ə weɪ aʊt, ðoʊ. . . . "haʊ? ðə plɛdʒ jə saɪn tə səpɔɹt mɑɹn əz bɪn poʊstɪɾ əkɹɔs hæf ʌv ændɝ baɪ naʊ. bɪsaɪdz, jə kən hɑɹdli θɪŋk ɛɹəmɪlə wɪl dʒʌst əlaʊ jə tə ɹaɪɾ əweɪ." nɑiən flɪntʃt, ən ɛləniə kəd nɑt hɛlp ə taɪt smaɪl. ðə wʊmən wɑz nɑt soʊ əntʌtʃt əz ʃi feɪnd. ʃi stɪl mænədʒ tə kip əɹ vɔɪs lɛvəl, ðoʊ.

"Do you think you can escape?" she asked quietly. Civility was all very well, but not at the expense of remaining here for all to see any longer than absolutely necessary. If Naean saw a way out, though. . . . "How? The pledge you signed to support Marne has been posted across half of Andor by now. Besides, you can hardly think Arymilla will just allow you to ride away." Naean flinched, and Elenia could not help a tight smile. The woman was not so untouched as she feigned. She still managed to keep her voice level, though.

"aɪ sɔ dʒɑɝɪd jɛstɝdeɪ, ɛləniə, ən ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns i lʊk laɪk ə θʌndɝklaʊd, ɡæləpɪŋ fɪt tə bɹeɪk ɪz maʊns nɛk ən ɪz oʊn. ɪf aɪ noʊ jəɹ hʌzbənd, hiz ɔlɹɛɾi plænɪŋ ə weɪ tə kʌt jə aʊɾ ə ðɪs. hi wəd spɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪ fəɹ ju." ðət wɑz tʃɹu; hi wʊd. "ɪm ʃʊɹ jə kən si ɪt wəd bi bɛst ɪf aɪ wɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðoʊz plænz."

"I saw Jarid yesterday, Elenia, and even at a distance he looked like a thundercloud, galloping fit to break his mount's neck and his own. If I know your husband, he's already planning a way to cut you out of this. He would spit in the Dark One's eye for you." That was true; he would. "I'm sure you can see it would be best if I were part of those plans."

"maɪ hʌzbən saɪn ðə seɪm plɛdʒ jə dɪd, nɑiən, ən hiz ən ɑnɝəbəl mæn." hi wɑz tu ɑnɝəbəl fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɡʊd, ɪn sɪmpəl fækt, bʌt wʌɾ ɛləniə wɑntəd hæd bɪn ɪz ɡaɪd sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ wɛɾɪŋ vaʊz. dʒɑɝɪd hæd saɪn ðə plɛdʒ kəz ʃi ɹoʊɾ ən toʊld ɪm tə, nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɛni tʃɔɪs əz mæɾɝz wɝ, ən i wəɾ ivən ɹipjuɾieɪt ɪt, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪlʌktənli, ɪf ʃi wɝ mæɾ ɪnʌf tə æsk ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ðə dɪfəkəlti ɪn lɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊ wʌt ʃi dɪd wɑn ət ðə moʊmənt. ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz vɛɹi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛɾ əɹ wɪðɪn ə maɪl ə hɪm. ʃi hæɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn hænd - əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəɾ ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz - bʌt ʃi niɾəd tə lɛt dʒɑɝɪd noʊ, ɪf oʊnli tə stɑp ɪm fɹəm "kʌɾɪŋ əɹ ə weɪ aʊt." spɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪ? hi kəd teɪk əm boʊθ tə ɹuən ɪn ðə bɪlif i wɑz hɛlpɪŋ hɝ, ən i maɪt də ɪɾ ivən noʊɪŋ ɪt mɛn ðɛɹ ɹuəneɪʃən.

"My husband signed the same pledge you did, Naean, and he is an honorable man." He was too honorable for his own good, in simple fact, but what Elenia wanted had been his guide since before their wedding vows. Jarid had signed the pledge because she wrote and told him to, not that she had any choice as matters were, and he would even repudiate it, however reluctantly, if she were mad enough to ask it. Of course, there was the difficulty in letting him know what she did want at the moment. Arymilla was very careful not to let her within a mile of him. She had everything in hand - as far as she could in the circumstances - but she needed to let Jarid know, if only to stop him from "cutting her a way out." Spit in the Dark One's eye? He could take them both to ruin in the belief he was helping her, and he might do it even knowing it meant their ruination.

ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt nɑt tə əlaʊ ðə fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ən fjʊɹi sʌɾənli wɛlɪŋ ʌp ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ tə ʃoʊ ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌt ʃi kʌvɝd ðə stʃɹeɪn wɪð ə smaɪl. ʃi tʊk kənsɪɾɝəbəl pɹaɪɾ ɪn biɪŋ eɪbəl tə pɹədus ə smaɪl fəɹ ɛni sɪtʃueɪʃən. ðɪs wʌn hɛld ə tʌtʃ ə sɝpɹaɪz. ən ə tʌtʃ ə dɪsdeɪn. "aɪm nɑt plænɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ, nɑiən, ən niðɝ ɪz dʒɑɝɪd, aɪm ʃʊɹ. bʌɾ ɪf aɪ wɝ, waɪ wəɾ aɪ ɪnklud ju?"

It required a great effort not to allow the frustration and fury suddenly welling up inside her to show on her face, but she covered the strain with a smile. She took considerable pride in being able to produce a smile for any situation. This one held a touch of surprise. And a touch of disdain. "I'm not planning anything, Naean, and neither is Jarid, I'm sure. But if I were, why would I include you?"

"bɪkɔz ɪf aɪm nɑɾ ɪnkluɾəd ɪn ðoʊz plænz," nɑiən sɛd blʌnli, "ɛɹəmɪlə maɪt lɝn ə ðɛm. ʃi meɪ bi ə blaɪn ful, bʌt ʃɪl si wʌns ʃiz toʊld wɛɹ tə lʊk. ən jə maɪt faɪn jɝsɛlf ʃɛɹɪŋ ə tɛnt wɪð jəɹ bɪtʃɹɑθd ɛvɹi naɪt, nɑt tə mɛnʃən pɹətɛktəd baɪ hɪz ɑɹmmɪn." ɛləniəz smaɪl mɛltəd, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs tɝn tə aɪs, mætʃɪŋ ðə fɹoʊzən bɔl ðəɾ əbɹʌpli fɪld əɹ stʌmək. "ju wɑnə bi kɛɹfəl wʌt jə seɪ, əɹ ɛɹəmɪlə meɪ æsk əɹ tæɹɑbənɝ tə pleɪ kæts kɹeɪɾəl wɪð jə əɡɛn. ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən ɡɛɹənti əz mʌtʃ." ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðət nɑiənz feɪs kəd ɡɹoʊ ɛni waɪɾɝ, jɛɾ ɪt dɪd. ʃi æktʃəli  sweɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ən kɑɾ ɛləniəz ɑɹm əz ɪf tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn flʌŋ əɹ kloʊk əbaʊt, ən ʃi lɛɾ ɪt fleɪl. ðoʊz wʌns-koʊld aɪz wɝ kwaɪt waɪd, naʊ. ðə wʊmən meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə haɪɾ əɹ fɪɹ.

"Because if I am not included in those plans," Naean said bluntly, "Arymilla might learn of them. She may be a blind fool, but she'll see once she's told where to look. And you might find yourself sharing a tent with your betrothed every night, not to mention protected by his armsmen." Elenia's smile melted, but her voice turned to ice, matching the frozen ball that abruptly filled her stomach. "You want to be careful what you say, or Arymilla may ask her Taraboner to play cat's cradle with you again. In truth, I think I can guarantee as much." It seemed impossible that Naean's face could grow any whiter, yet it did. She actually swayed in her saddle, and caught Elenia's arm as if to keep from falling. A gust of wind flung her cloak about, and she let it flail. Those once-cold eyes were quite wide, now. The woman made no effort to hide her fear.

pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tu fɑɹ ɡɔn tə bi keɪpəbəl ə haɪɾɪŋ ɪt. hɝ vɔɪs keɪm bɹɛθi ən pænɪkt. "aɪ noʊ jə ən dʒɑɝɪɾ ɑɹ plænɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ɛləniə. aɪ noʊ ɪt! teɪk mi wɪð ju, ən . . . ən əl plɛdʒ ɑɝɔn tə jə əz sun əz aɪ kən bi fɹi ʌv ɛɹəmɪlə." oʊ, ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkən, tə ɔfɝ ðæt.

Perhaps she was too far gone to be capable of hiding it. Her voice came breathy and panicked. "I know you and Jarid are planning something, Elenia. I know it! Take me with you, and . . . and I will pledge Arawn to you as soon as I can be free of Arymilla." Oh, she was shaken, to offer that.

"du jə wɑnə dʒɹɔ mɔɹ ətɛnʃən ðən jə ɔlɹɛɾi hæv?" ɛləniə snæpt, pʊlɪŋ fɹi ʌv ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ɡɹæsp. dɔn wɪn ən ðə blæk ɡɛldɪŋ dæns nɝvəsli, kætʃɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz' mudz, ən ɛləniə ɹeɪn əɹ beɪ hɑɹd tə kwaɪət hɪm. tu ʌv ðə mɛn ət ðə faɪɝ hɝidli pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn.

"Do you want to draw more attention than you already have?" Elenia snapped, pulling free of the other woman's grasp. Dawn Wind and the black gelding danced nervously, catching their riders' moods, and Elenia reined her bay hard to quiet him. Two of the men at the fire hurriedly put their heads down.

noʊ daʊt ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ sɔ tu noʊbəlwɪmən ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ ivnɪŋ ən wɑntəd tə ətʃɹæk noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðəɾ æŋɡɝ ɑn ðɛmsɛlvz. jɛs; ɪt mʌs bi oʊnli ðæt. ðeɪ maɪt kæɹi teɪlz, bʌt ðeɪ nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə ɡɛt mɪkst ɪn ðɛɹ bɛɾɝz' ɑɹɡjəməns.

No doubt they thought they saw two noblewomen arguing in the graying evening and wanted to attract no part of that anger on themselves. Yes; it must be only that. They might carry tales, but they knew better than to get mixed in their betters' arguments.

"aɪ hæv noʊ plænz tə . . . ɪskeɪp; nʌn əɾ ɔl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kwaɪəɾɝ vɔɪs. dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ kloʊk kloʊs əɡɛn, ʃi kɑmli tɝn əɹ hɛd tə tʃɛk ðə kɑɹts, ən ðə nɪɹəs tɛns. ɪf nɑiən wɑz fɹaɪɾənd ɪnʌf. . . . wən ən oʊpənɪŋ pɹizɛntəɾ ɪtsɛlf. . . . ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ, bʌt ʃi stɪl kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs loʊ. "mæɾɝz maɪt tʃeɪnʒ, ʌv kɔɹs. hu kən seɪ? ɪf ðeɪ du, aɪ meɪk jə ðɪs pɹɑməs, ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ maɪ hoʊp ə ɹibɝθ, əl nɑt liv wɪθaʊt ju." ə stɑɹɾəld hoʊp blumd ɑn nɑiənz feɪs. naʊ tə pɹizɛn ðə hʊk. "ɪf, ðəɾ ɪz, aɪ hæv ɪn maɪ pəzɛʃən ə lɛɾɝ ɹɪɾən ɪn jəɹ oʊn hænd, saɪn ən sild, ɪn wɪtʃ jə ɪksplɪsətli ɹipjuɾieɪt jəɹ səpɔɹɾ ə mɑɹn, ʌv jəɹ oʊn fɹi wɪl, ən swɛɹ ðə səpɔɹɾ ə haʊs ɑɝɔn tə mi fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn. ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ jəɹ hoʊp ə ɹibɝθ. nʌθɪŋ lɛs wɪl du." nɑiənz hɛd dʒɝk bæk, ən ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps wɪð əɹ tʌŋ. hɝ aɪz ʃɪftəɾ əz ðoʊ sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ aʊt, fəɹ hɛlp. ðə blæk kəntɪnjud tə snɔɹɾ ən dæns, bʌt ʃi bɛɹli taɪɾənd əɹ ɹeɪnz ɪnʌf tə kip ɪm fɹəm boʊltɪŋ, ən ivən ðət simd ʌnkɑnʃəs. jɛs, ʃi wɑz fɹaɪɾənd. bʌt nɑt tu fɹaɪɾənd tə noʊ wʌɾ ɛləniə wɑz dɪmændɪŋ. ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ændɝ kənteɪn tu mɛni ɪɡzæmpəlz fəɹ əɹ nɑt tə noʊ. ə θaʊzən pɑsəbɪləɾiz ɹɪmeɪn soʊ lɔŋ əz nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðə mɪɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ə sətʃ ə lɛɾɝ wəd pʊɾ ə bɪt bɪtwin nɑiənz tiθ ən ðə ɹeɪnz ɪn ɛləniəz hænz. pʌbləkeɪʃən mɛnt nɑiənz dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, ənlɛs ɛləniə wɑz ful ɪnʌf tə ədmɪt tə koʊɝʃən. ʃi kəd tʃɹaɪ tə hæŋ ɑn æftɝ ðət ɹɛvəleɪʃən, jɛɾ ivən ə haʊs wɪð mɛni fjuɝ æntæɡənɪzəmz bɪtwin ɪts mɛmbɝz ðən ɑɝɔn, mɛni fjuɝ kʌzənz ən æns ən ʌŋkəlz ɹɛɾi tə ʌndɝkʌt wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, wəd stɪl bɹeɪk əpɑɹt. ðə lɛsɝ haʊsəz ðət hæd bɪn taɪd tə ɑɝɔn fəɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz wəd sik pɹətɛkʃən ɛlswɛɹ. ɪn ə mæɾɝ ə jɪɹz, ɪf nɑt sunɝ, nɑiən wəd bi lɛft əz ðə haɪ siɾ ʌv ə maɪnɝ ən dɪskɹɛɾɪtɪd ɹɛmnənt. oʊ, jɛs; ɪt hæd hæpən bɪfɔɹ.

"I have no plans to . . . escape; none at all," she said in a quieter voice. Drawing her cloak close again, she calmly turned her head to check the carts, and the nearest tents. If Naean was frightened enough. . . . When an opening presented itself. . . . There was no one close enough to overhear, but she still kept her voice low. "Matters might change, of course. Who can say? If they do, I make you this promise, under the Light and by my hope of rebirth, I will not leave without you." A startled hope bloomed on Naean's face. Now to present the hook. "If, that is, I have in my possession a letter written in your own hand, signed and sealed, in which you explicitly repudiate your support of Marne, of your own free will, and swear the support of House Arawn to me for the throne. Under the Light and by your hope of rebirth. Nothing less will do." Naean's head jerked back, and she touched her lips with her tongue. Her eyes shifted as though searching for a way out, for help. The black continued to snort and dance, but she barely tightened her reins enough to keep him from bolting, and even that seemed unconscious. Yes, she was frightened. But not too frightened to know what Elenia was demanding. The history of Andor contained too many examples for her not to know. A thousand possibilities remained so long as nothing was in writing, but the mere existence of such a letter would put a bit between Naean's teeth and the reins in Elenia's hands. Publication meant Naean's destruction, unless Elenia was fool enough to admit to coercion. She could try to hang on after that revelation, yet even a House with many fewer antagonisms between its members than Arawn, many fewer cousins and aunts and uncles ready to undercut one another in a heartbeat, would still break apart. The lesser Houses that had been tied to Arawn for generations would seek protection elsewhere. In a matter of years, if not sooner, Naean would be left as the High Seat of a minor and discredited remnant. Oh, yes; it had happened before.

"wiv bɪn təɡɛðɝ lɔŋ ɪnʌf." ɛləniə ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz. "aɪ wʊdnt wɑnə sɛt tʌŋz wæɡɪŋ. pɝhæps wɪl əv ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə spik əloʊn bɪfɔɹ ɛɹəmɪlə teɪks ðə θɹoʊn." wʌɾ ə vaɪl θɔt! "pɝhæps."

"We've been together long enough." Elenia gathered her reins. "I wouldn't want to set tongues wagging. Perhaps we will have another chance to speak alone before Arymilla takes the throne." What a vile thought! "Perhaps."

ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɛksheɪld əz ɪf ɔl ə ðə bɹɛθ ɪn əɹ bɑɾi wɝ likɪŋ aʊt, bʌɾ ɛləniə wɛn ɑn əbaʊt tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs əweɪ, niðɝ sloʊli nɔɹ ɪn heɪst, nɑt stɑpɪŋ əntɪl nɑiən sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, "weɪt!"

The other woman exhaled as if all of the breath in her body were leaking out, but Elenia went on about turning her horse away, neither slowly nor in haste, not stopping until Naean said urgently, "Wait!"

lʊkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ʃi dɪd dʒʌs ðæt. weɪɾəd. wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ ə wɝd. wʌt niɾəd tə bi sɛd hæd bɪn sɛd. ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪnd wɑz tə si wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən wɑz dɛspɹɪɾ ɪnʌf tə dɪlɪvɝ hɝsɛlf ɪndə ɛləniəz hænz. ʃi ʃəd bi. ʃi hæd noʊ dʒɑɝɪd tə wɝk fəɹ hɝ. ɪn fækt, ɛniwʌn ɪn ɑɝɔn u sədʒɛstəd ðət nɑiən niɾəd ɹɛskjuɪŋ laɪkli wəd faɪn hɝsɛlf ɪmpɹɪzən fəɹ θwɔɹɾɪŋ nɑiənz ɪkspɹɛst wɪl. wɪθaʊɾ ɛləniə, ʃi kəd ɡɹoʊ oʊld ɪn kæptɪvəɾi. wɪð ðə lɛɾɝ, ðoʊ, hɝ kæptɪvəɾi wəd bi ʌv ə dɪfɹən kaɪnd. wɪð ðə lɛɾɝ, ɛləniə wəd bi eɪbəl tə əlaʊ hɝ ɛvɹi əpɪɹəns ə kəmplit fɹiɾəm. əpɛɹənli ʃi wɑz bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə si ðæt. əɹ meɪbi dʒʌs fɹaɪɾənd ɪnʌf ə ðə tæɹɑbənɝ.

Looking back over her shoulder, she did just that. Waited. Without speaking a word. What needed to be said had been said. All that remained was to see whether the woman was desperate enough to deliver herself into Elenia's hands. She should be. She had no Jarid to work for her. In fact, anyone in Arawn who suggested that Naean needed rescuing likely would find herself imprisoned for thwarting Naean's expressed will. Without Elenia, she could grow old in captivity. With the letter, though, her captivity would be of a different kind. With the letter, Elenia would be able to allow her every appearance of complete freedom. Apparently she was bright enough to see that. Or maybe just frightened enough of the Taraboner.

"aɪ wɪl ɡɛɾ ɪt tə jə əz sun əz aɪ kæn," ʃi sɛɾ ət læst, ɪn ə ɹɪzaɪn vɔɪs.

"I will get it to you as soon as I can," she said at last, in a resigned voice.

"aɪ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə siɪŋ ɪt," ɛləniə mɝmɝd, bɛɹli bɑðɝɪŋ tə mæsk əɹ sæɾəsfækʃən. bʌt doʊnt weɪt tu lɔŋ, ʃi ɔlmoʊst æɾəd, ən dʒʌst stɑp hɝsɛlf. nɑiən maɪt bi biɾən, bʌɾ ə biɾən foʊ kəd stɪl pʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn jəɹ bæk ɪf ɡoʊɾɪd tu fɑɹ. bɪsaɪdz wɪtʃ, ʃi fɪɹd nɑiənz θɹɛɾ əz mʌtʃ əz nɑiən fɪɹd hɝz. pɝhæps mɔɹ. soʊ lɔŋ əz nɑiən dɪd nɑt noʊ ðæt, haʊɛvɝ, hɝ bleɪd hæd noʊ pɔɪnt.

"I look forward to seeing it," Elenia murmured, barely bothering to mask her satisfaction. But don't wait too long, she almost added, and just stopped herself. Naean might be beaten, but a beaten foe could still put a knife in your back if goaded too far. Besides which, she feared Naean's threat as much as Naean feared hers. Perhaps more. So long as Naean did not know that, however, her blade had no point.

əz ʃi ɹoʊd bæk tə hɝ ɑɹmmɪn, ɛləniəz mud wɑz mɔɹ bɔɪən ðən ɪt hæd bɪn sɪns. . . .

As she rode back to her armsmen, Elenia's mood was more buoyant than it had been since. . . .

sɝɾənli sɪns bɪfɔɹ əɹ "ɹeɪz kɝz" hæd tɝn aʊt tə bi ɛɹəmɪləz mɛn. pɝhæps sɪns bɪfɔɹ daɪɛlɪn hæɾ ɪmpɹɪzən əɹ ɪn ɑɹɪŋɡəl ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ lɔs hoʊp ðɛɹ. hɝ pɹɪzən hæd bɪn ðə ɡʌvɝnɝz haʊs, kwaɪt kʌmftəɹbəl, ivən ɪf ʃi hæd tə ʃɛɹ ən əpɑɹtmənt wɪð nɑiən.

Certainly since before her "res cuers" had turned out to be Arymilla's men. Perhaps since before Dyelin had imprisoned her in Aringill in the first place, though she had never lost hope there. Her prison had been the governor's house, quite comfortable, even if she had to share an apartment with Naean.

kəmjunəkeɪɾɪŋ wɪð dʒɑɝɪd sɝɾənli hæd pɹizɛntəd noʊ pɹɑbləm, ən ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd meɪd səm ɪnɹoʊdz wɪð ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɪn ɑɹɪŋɡəl. soʊ mɛni ʌv əm hæd bɪn nu-kʌm aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin ðət ðeɪ wɝ . . . ənʃʊɹ . . . wɛɹ ðɛɹ tʃɹu lɔɪəltiz leɪ.

Communicating with Jarid certainly had presented no problem, and she thought she had made some inroads with the Queen's Guards in Aringill. So many of them had been new-come out of Cairhien that they were . . . unsure . . . where their true loyalties lay.

naʊ, ðɪs wʌndɝfəli fɔɹtuɪɾəs ɪnkaʊntɝ wɪð nɑiən lɪftəɾ əɹ spɪɹəts soʊ mʌtʃ ðət ʃi smaɪld ət dʒæni ən pɹɑməst əɹ ə bɛvi ʌv nu dʒɹɛsəz wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɪnsaɪd keɪɛmlɪn. wɪtʃ pɹədust ə pɹɑpɝli ɡɹeɪtfəl smaɪl fɹəm ðə plʌmp-tʃikt wʊmən. ɛləniə ɔlweɪz bɑt nu dʒɹɛsəz fəɹ əɹ meɪd wən ʃi fɛl pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɡʊd, ɛvɹi wʌn faɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ə səksɛsfəl mɝtʃənt. ɪt wɑz wʌn weɪ tə ɪnʃʊɹ lɔɪəlti ən dɪskɹɛʃən, ən fəɹ twɛnti jɪɹz, dʒæni hæd dɪlɪvɝd boʊθ.

Now, this wonderfully fortuitous encounter with Naean lifted her spirits so much that she smiled at Janny and promised her a bevy of new dresses once they were inside Caemlyn. Which produced a properly grateful smile from the plump-cheeked woman. Elenia always bought new dresses for her maid when she felt particularly good, every one fine enough for a successful merchant. It was one way to insure loyalty and discretion, and for twenty years, Janny had delivered both.

ðə sʌn wɑz oʊnli ə ɹɛd ɹɪm əbʌv ðə tʃɹiz naʊ, ən ɪt wɑz taɪm tə faɪn ɛɹəmɪlə soʊ ʃi kəd bi toʊld wɛɹ ʃi wɑz slipɪŋ tənaɪt. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt wɑz ə disən bɛd, ɪn ə wɔɹm tɛn ðət wɑz nɑt tu smoʊki, wɪð ə disən mil bɪfɔɹhænd. ʃi kəd nɑɾ æsk mɔɹ, ət pɹɛzənt. ivən ðət dɪd nɑt dɛn əɹ mud, ðoʊ. ʃi nɑɾ oʊnli nɑɾəd tə ðə klʌstɝz ə mɛn ən wɪmən ðeɪ ɹoʊd pæst, ʃi smaɪld ət ðɛm. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə weɪv. mæɾɝz wɝ pɹəɡɹɛsɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn kwaɪt səm taɪm. nɑiən wɑz nɑt sɪmpli dɪspoʊzd ʌv əz ə ɹaɪvəl fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn, ʃi hæd bɪn liʃt ən bɹɔt tə hil, əɹ əz ɡʊɾ æz, ən ðət maɪt - wʊd! - bi səfɪʃən tə bɹɪŋ kɑɝɪn ən lɝ. ən ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u wəɾ æksɛpt ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ənʌðɝ tʃɹəkən ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. ɛlɹin, fəɹ wʌn. mɔɹɡeɪs hæd hæɾ əɹ flɑɡdbækslæʃ ɛlɹin wəd nɛvɝ stæn fəɹ ɛni tʃɹəkənd. æɛmlɪn, ɑɝəθɛl ən æbəl wɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz, tu, wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn ɡɹivənsəz ðət kəd bi ɛksplɔɪɾəd. pɝhæps pɛlɪvɑɹ əɹ lwɑn, əz wɛl.

The sun was only a red rim above the trees now, and it was time to find Arymilla so she could be told where she was sleeping tonight. The Light send it was a decent bed, in a warm tent that was not too smoky, with a decent meal beforehand. She could not ask more, at present. Even that did not dent her mood, though. She not only nodded to the clusters of men and women they rode past, she smiled at them. She almost went so far as to wave. Matters were progressing better than they had in quite some time. Naean was not simply disposed of as a rival for the throne, she had been leashed and brought to heel, or as good as, and that might - would! - be sufficient to bring Karind and Lir. And there were those who would accept anyone other than another Trakand on the throne. Ellorien, for one. Morgase had had her flogged\ Ellorien would never stand for any Trakand. Aemlyn, Arathelle and Abelle were possibilities, too, with their own grievances that could be exploited. Perhaps Pelivar or Luan, as well.

ʃi hæɾ əɹ filɝz aʊt. ən ʃi wəd nɑt skwɑndɝ ði ædvæntɪdʒ ə keɪɛmlɪn, əz ðət hɔɪɾən ɪleɪn hæd. hɪstɔɹɪkəli, hoʊldɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɡæðɝ ðə səpɔɹɾ ʌv ət lis fɔɹ əɹ faɪv haʊsəz baɪ ɪtsɛlf. ðə taɪmɪŋ wəd bi ki, sɝɾənli, əɹ ɔl ði ædvæntɪdʒ wəd fɔl tə ɛɹəmɪlə, bʌɾ ɛləniə kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi si hɝsɛlf siɾəd ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, wɪð ðə haɪ sits nilɪŋ tə swɛɹ fiəlti. ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ əɹ lɪst ʌv wɪtʃ haɪ sits wəd nid tə bi ɹipleɪst. noʊ wʌn u hæɾ əpoʊzd əɹ wɑz gɑnə bi əlaʊd tə kɑz əɹ tʃɹʌbəl leɪɾɝ. ə sɪɹiz ʌv ənfɔɹtʃənəɾ æksəɾənts wəd si tə ðæt. ə pɪɾi ʃi kəd nɑt tʃuz ðɛɹ ɹipleɪsməns, bʌɾ æksəɾənts kəd hæpən wɪð ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl fɹikwənsi.

She had her feelers out. And she would not squander the advantage of Caemlyn, as that hoyden Elayne had. Historically, holding Caemlyn was enough to gather the support of at least four or five Houses by itself. The timing would be key, certainly, or all the advantage would fall to Arymilla, but Elenia could already see herself seated on the Lion Throne, with the High Seats kneeling to swear fealty. She already had her list of which High Seats would need to be replaced. No one who had opposed her was going to be allowed to cause her trouble later. A series of unfortunate accidents would see to that. A pity she could not choose their replacements, but accidents could happen with incredible frequency.

hɝ hæpi kɑntəmpleɪʃən wɑz ʃæɾɝd baɪ ðə skɹɔni mæn u sʌɾənli keɪm ʌp bɪsaɪɾ əɹ ɑn ə stɑki ɡɹeɪ, hɪz aɪz fɛvɝɪʃli bɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə feɪɾɪŋ laɪt. fəɹ səm ɹizən, næsən hæd spɹɪɡz ʌv ɡɹin fɝ stʌk ɪn ɪz θɪn waɪt hɛɹ. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm lʊk əz ɪf i hæd bɪn klaɪmɪŋ ɪn ə tʃɹi, ən ɪz ɹɛd sɪlk koʊɾ ən kloʊk wɝ soʊ wɝkt wɪð bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd flaʊɝz ðeɪ cʊɾə pæs fəɹ ɪliɑnɝ kɑɹpəts. hi wɑz luɾəkɹəs. hi wɑz ɔlsoʊ haɪ siɾ ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl sɪŋɡəl haʊs ɪn ændɝ. ən i wɑz kwaɪt mæd. "ɛləniə, maɪ dɑɹlɪŋ tʃɹɛʒɝ," hi bɹeɪd, spɹeɪɪŋ spɪɾəl, "haʊ swit ðə saɪɾ ə jə ɪz tə maɪ aɪz. jə meɪk hʌni sim steɪl ən ɹoʊzɪz dʒɹæb."

Her happy contemplation was shattered by the scrawny man who suddenly came up beside her on a stocky gray, his eyes feverishly bright in the fading light. For some reason, Nasin had sprigs of green fir stuck in his thin white hair. It made him look as if he had been climbing in a tree, and his red silk coat and cloak were so worked with brightly colored flowers they could have passed for Illianer carpets. He was ludicrous. He was also High Seat of the most powerful single House in Andor. And he was quite mad. "Elenia, my darling treasure," he brayed, spraying spittle, "how sweet the sight of you is to my eyes. You make honey seem stale and roses drab."

wɪθaʊt nid fəɹ kɑnʃəs θɔt, ʃi heɪstəli ɹeɪn dɔn wɪn bæk ən tə ðə ɹaɪt, pʊɾɪŋ dʒæniz bɹaʊn mɛɹ bɪtwin əɹ ən hɪm. "aɪ æm nɑt jəɹ bɪtʃɹɑθd, næsən," ʃi snæpt, siθɪŋ ət hævɪŋ tə seɪ ðəɾ əlaʊd fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə hɪɹ. "aɪ æm mɛɹid, jə oʊl ful! weɪt!" ʃi æɾəd, flɪŋɪŋ ʌp ə hænd. ði ɪmpɛɹəɾɪv wɝɾ ən ðə dʒɛstʃɝ wɝ fəɹ əɹ ɑɹmmɪn, hu hæd leɪd hænz ɑn sɔɹd hɪls ən wɝ ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət næsən. səm θɝɾi əɹ fɔɹɾi mɛn wɛɹɪŋ haʊs kɝənz sɔɹɾ ən stɑɹ wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ðə mæn, ən ðeɪ wəd nɑt hɛzəteɪt tə kʌt daʊn ɛniwʌn ðeɪ θɔt wɑz θɹɛɾənɪŋ ðɛɹ haɪ sit. səm ɔlɹɛɾi hæd bleɪdz hæf-dʒɹɔn. ðeɪ wəd nɑt hɑɹm hɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. næsən wəɾ əv əm hæŋ tə ə mæn ɪf ʃi wɑz ivən bɹuzd. laɪt, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ oʊvɝ ðæt. "ɑɹ jə stɪl əfɹeɪɾ ə ðət jʌŋ ɑf dʒɑɝɪd?" næsən dɪmændəd, æŋɡlɪŋ ɪz maʊn tə fɑloʊ hɝ.

Without need for conscious thought, she hastily reined Dawn Wind back and to the right, putting Janny's brown mare between her and him. "I am not your betrothed, Nasin," she snapped, seething at having to say that aloud for everyone to hear. "I am married, you old fool! Wait!" she added, flinging up a hand. The imperative word and the gesture were for her armsmen, who had laid hands on sword hilts and were glaring at Nasin. Some thirty or forty men wearing House Caeren's Sword and Star were following the man, and they would not hesitate to cut down anyone they thought was threatening their High Seat. Some already had blades half-drawn. They would not harm her, of course. Nasin would have them hanged to a man if she was even bruised. Light, she did not know whether to laugh or cry over that. "Are you still afraid of that young oaf Jarid?" Nasin demanded, angling his mount to follow her.

"hi hæz noʊ ɹaɪt tə kip bɑðɝɪŋ ju. ðə bɛɾɝ mæn wʌn, ən i ʃəɾ æknɑlɪdʒ ɪt. əl tʃælənʒ hɪm!" wʌn hænd, pleɪnli boʊni ivən ɪn ɪts taɪt ɹɛd ɡlʌv, fʌmbəld əɾ ə sɔɹɾ i pɹɑbli hæd nɑt dʒɹɔn ɪn twɛnti jɪɹz. "aɪ wɪl kʌɾ ɪm daʊn laɪk ə dɔɡ fəɹ fɹaɪɾənɪŋ ju!" ɛləniə muv dɔn wɪn dɛfli, soʊ ðeɪ dɪskɹaɪbd ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn dʒæni, hu mɝmɝɾ əpɑlədʒiz tə næsən ən pɹitɛndəd tə teɪk əɹ mɛɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ waɪl ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn ɪt. mɛntəli, ɛləniə æɾəd ə lɪɾəl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi tə ðə dʒɹɛsəz ʃi wəd baɪ. æəlpeɪɾɪd əz i wɑz, næsən kəd ɡoʊ ɪn ə blɪŋk fɹəm hʌnid wɝdz ə kɔɹtli lʌv tə ɡɹoʊpɪŋ əɾ əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ðə loʊəst sɔɹɾ ə tævɝn meɪd.

"He has no right to keep bothering you. The better man won, and he should acknowledge it. I'll challenge him!" One hand, plainly bony even in its tight red glove, fumbled at a sword he probably had not drawn in twenty years. "I will cut him down like a dog for frightening you!" Elenia moved Dawn Wind deftly, so they described a circle around Janny, who murmured apologies to Nasin and pretended to take her mare out of his way while getting in it. Mentally, Elenia added a little embroidery to the dresses she would buy. Addlepated as he was, Nasin could go in a blink from honeyed words of courtly love to groping at her as if she were the lowest sort of tavern maid.

ðæt, ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɛndʒjʊɹ, nɑɾ əɡɛn, sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪn pʌblɪk. sɝkəlɪŋ, ʃi fɔɹst ə wɝid smaɪl ɑntu hɝ feɪs, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðə smaɪl tʊk mɔɹ ɛfɝt ðən ðə wɝi. ɪf ðɪs oʊl ful fɔɹs dʒɑɝɪd tə kɪl hɪm, ɪt wəd ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ! "ju noʊ aɪ kəd nɑɾ əbaɪd tə hæv mɛn faɪɾ oʊvɝ mi, næsən." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz bɹɛθi ən æŋkʃəs, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. bɹɛθi ən æŋkʃəs suɾəd wɛl ɪnʌf. "haʊ kəɾ aɪ lʌv ə mæn wɪð blʌɾ ɑn ɪz hænz?" ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs mæn fɹaʊn daʊn ðət lɔŋ noʊz tɪl ʃi bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ʃi hæd ɡɔn tu fɑɹ. hi wɑz mæɾ əz ə spɹɪŋ hɛɹ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ. nɑɾ ɔlweɪz. "aɪ hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz jə wɝ soʊ . . . sɛnsəɾɪv," hi sɛd faɪnəli. wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ ɪz ɛfɝt tə ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn dʒæni. hɪz dəkɹɛpɪt feɪs bɹaɪɾənd. "bʌɾ aɪ ʃəɾ əv noʊn. əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ, fɹəm naʊ ɑn. dʒɑɝɪd meɪ lɪv. soʊ lɔŋ əz i dʌzn pɛstɝ ju." əbɹʌpli, hi sim tə noʊɾəs dʒæni fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ən wɪð ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɡɹɪmɑs, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn haɪ, bɔlɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ə fɪst.

That, she could not endure, not again, certainly not in public. Circling, she forced a worried smile onto her face, though in truth, the smile took more effort than the worry. If this old fool forced Jarid to kill him, it would ruin everything! "You know I could not abide to have men fight over me, Nasin." Her voice was breathy and anxious, but she did not try to control it. Breathy and anxious suited well enough. "How could I love a man with blood on his hands?" The ridiculous man frowned down that long nose till she began to wonder whether she had gone too far. He was mad as a spring hare, but not in everything. Not always. "I had not realized you were so . . . sensitive," he said finally. Without stopping his effort to ride around Janny. His decrepit face brightened. "But I should have known. I will remember, from now on. Jarid may live. So long as he doesn't pester you." Abruptly, he seemed to notice Janny for the first time, and with an irritated grimace, he raised his hand high, balling it into a fist.

ðə plʌmp wʊmən vɪzəbli stil hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðə bloʊ wɪθaʊt muvɪŋ əsaɪd, ən ɛləniə ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ. sɪlk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. dɛfənətli ənsuɾəbəl fəɹ ə meɪd, bʌt dʒæni hæɾ ɝn ɪt.

The plump woman visibly steeled herself for the blow without moving aside, and Elenia gritted her teeth. Silk embroidery. Definitely unsuitable for a maid, but Janny had earned it.

"lɔɹd næsən, aɪ hæv bɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ jə ɛvɹiwɛɹ" ə wʊmənz sɪmpɝɪŋ vɔɪs kɹaɪd, ən ðə sɝkəlɪŋ stɑpt. ɛləniə ɛksheɪld ɪn ɹɪlif əz ɛɹəmɪlə ɹoʊɾ ʌp ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪt wɪð əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ, ən hæd tə staɪfəl ə sɝdʒ ə fjʊɹi ət filɪŋ ɹɪlif. ɪn oʊvɝ-ɪlæbɹətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin sɪlk, wɪð leɪs ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn ən əɾ əɹ ɹɪsts, ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz plʌmp vɝdʒɪŋ ɑn staʊt, wɪð ə vækjuəs smaɪl ən bɹaʊn aɪz ðət wɝ ɔlweɪz waɪd wɪð əfɛktəɾ ɪntʃɹəst ivən wən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn. lækɪŋ ðə bɹeɪnz tə tɛl ðə dɪfɝəns, ʃi pəzɛs dʒʌst ɪnʌf kʌnɪŋ tə noʊ ðəɹ wɝ θɪŋz ðət ʃəɾ ɪntʃɹəs hɝ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk ʃi hæd mɪs ðɛm. ði oʊnli ɹil kənsɝn ʃi hæd wɑz əɹ oʊn kʌmfɝɾ ən ði ɪnkʌm tə ɛnʃʊɹ ɪt, ən ði oʊnli ɹizən ʃi wɑntəd ðə θɹoʊn wɑz ðət ðə ɹɔɪəl kɑfɝz kəd pɹəvaɪd ɡɹeɪɾɝ kʌmfɝt ðən ðə ɹɛvənuz ʌv ɛni haɪ sit. hɝ ɑntʊɹɑʒ wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ ðən næsənz, ðoʊ oʊnli hæf wɝ ɑɹmmɪn wɛɹɪŋ ðə fɔɹ munz ə hɝ haʊs. fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, hæŋɝz-ɑn ən sɪkɑfæns meɪɾ ʌp ðə ɹɛst, lɛsɝ lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz ə maɪnɝ haʊsəz ən ʌðɝz wɪlɪŋ tə lɪk ɛɹəmɪləz ɹɪs fəɹ ə pleɪs nɪɹ paʊɝ. ʃi dɪd lʌv pipəl tə fɔn oʊvɝ hɝ. nɑiən wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹup wɪð əɹ ɑɹmmɪn ən meɪd, əpɛɹənli kul-aɪɾ ən ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə hɝsɛlf wʌns mɔɹ. bʌt kipɪŋ wɛl əweɪ fɹəm dʒæk laʊnɔlt, ə lin mæn wɪð wʌn ə ðoʊz fɑɹsəkəl tæɹɑbənɝ veɪlz kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz hjudʒ mʌstæʃɪz ən ə kɑnɪkəl kæp pʊʃɪŋ ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk tə ə ɹɪdɪkjələs haɪt. ðə fɛloʊ smaɪl tu mʌtʃ, əz wɛl. hi hɑɹdli lʊkt ə mæn u kəd ɹədus sʌmwʌn tə bɛɡɪŋ wɪð dʒʌst ə fju kɔɹdz. "ɛɹəmɪlə," næsən sɛɾ ɪn ə kənfjuz toʊn, ðən fɹaʊn əɾ ɪz fɪst əz ɪf sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪt ɹeɪzd. loʊɝɪŋ ɪz hæn tə ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, hi bimd ə smaɪl ət ðə sɪli wʊmən. "ɛɹəmɪlə, maɪ dɪɹ," hi sɛd wɔɹmli. nɑt wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wɔɹmθ i ɔfən dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɛləniə. sʌmhaʊ, ɪt simd, hi hæd bɪkʌm ət lis hæf-kənvɪns ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz ɪz dɔɾɝ, ən ɪz feɪvɹɪɾ ət ðæt. wʌns, ɛləniə hæd hɝɾ ɪm ɹɛmənɪsɪŋ ət lɛŋθ wɪð ðə wʊmən əbaʊɾ əɹ "mʌðɝ," hɪz læst waɪf, dɛd nɪɹli θɝɾi jɪɹz naʊ. ɛɹəmɪlə mænədʒ tə hoʊld əɹ ɛn ə ðə kɑnvɝseɪʃən, tu, ðoʊ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ mɛt midɛl kɝən əz fɑɹ əz ɛləniə nu. stɪl, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ɪz fɑðɝli smaɪlz fəɹ ɛɹəmɪlə, hɪz aɪz sɔt θɹu ðə ʃæɾoʊd kɹaʊɾ ɑn hɔɹsbæk bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən ɪz feɪs ɹɪlækst wən i faʊn sɪlveɪs, hɪz ɡɹændɔɾɝ ən ɛɹ, ə stɝɾi, plæsəd jʌŋ wʊmən u mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz, ənsmaɪlɪŋ, ðən pʊld əɹ dɑɹk, fɝ-laɪn kaʊl wɛl fɔɹwɝd. ʃi nɛvɝ smaɪld əɹ fɹaʊn əɹ ʃoʊɾ ɛni ɪmoʊʃən əɾ ɔl ðəɾ ɛləniə hæɾ ɛvɝ dɪtɛktəd, dʒʌs kɛpt ən ənvɹiɪŋ kaʊlaɪk ɪkspɹɛʃən.

"Lord Nasin, I have been looking for you everywhere" a woman's simpering voice cried, and the circling stopped. Elenia exhaled in relief as Arymilla rode up in the twilight with her entourage, and had to stifle a surge of fury at feeling relief. In over-elaborately embroidered green silk, with lace under her chin and at her wrists, Arymilla was plump verging on stout, with a vacuous smile and brown eyes that were always wide with affected interest even when there was nothing to be interested in. Lacking the brains to tell the difference, she possessed just enough cunning to know there were things that should interest her, and she did not want anyone to think she had missed them. The only real concern she had was her own comfort and the income to ensure it, and the only reason she wanted the throne was that the royal coffers could provide greater comfort than the revenues of any High Seat. Her entourage was larger than Nasin's, though only half were armsmen wearing the Four Moons of her House. For the most part, hangers-on and sycophants made up the rest, lesser lords and ladies of minor Houses and others willing to lick Arymilla's wrist for a place near power. She did love people to fawn over her. Naean was there, too, on the edge of the group with her armsmen and maid, apparently cool-eyed and in control of herself once more. But keeping well away from Jaq Lounalt, a lean man with one of those farcical Taraboner veils covering his huge mustaches and a conical cap pushing the hood of his cloak to a ridiculous height. The fellow smiled too much, as well. He hardly looked a man who could reduce someone to begging with just a few cords. "Arymilla," Nasin said in a confused tone, then frowned at his fist as if surprised to find it raised. Lowering his hand to the pommel of his saddle, he beamed a smile at the silly woman. "Arymilla, my dear," he said warmly. Not with the sort of warmth he often directed at Elenia. Somehow, it seemed, he had become at least half-convinced that Arymilla was his daughter, and his favorite at that. Once, Elenia had heard him reminiscing at length with the woman about her "mother," his last wife, dead nearly thirty years now. Arymilla managed to hold her end of the conversation, too, though she had never met Miedelle Caeren as far as Elenia knew. Still, despite all his fatherly smiles for Arymilla, his eyes sought through the shadowed crowd on horseback behind her, and his face relaxed when he found Sylvase, his granddaughter and heir, a sturdy, placid young woman who met his gaze, unsmiling, then pulled her dark, fur-lined cowl well forward. She never smiled or frowned or showed any emotion at all that Elenia had ever detected, just kept an unvarying cowlike expression.

pleɪnli, ʃi hæɾ ə kaʊz wɪts, tu. ɛɹəmɪlə kɛp sɪlveɪs kloʊsɝ ðən ʃi dɪɾ ɛləniə əɹ nɑiən, ən soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns ðət næsən wəd bi fɔɹs tə ɹɪtaɪɹ fɹəm ɪz ɑnɝz. hi wɑz mæd, əʃʊɹədli, bʌt slaɪ. "aɪ hoʊp jəɹ teɪkɪŋ ɡʊd kɛɹ ə maɪ lɪɾəl sɪlveɪs, ɛɹəmɪlə," hi mɝmɝd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹtʃən hʌntɝz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən aɪ wɑn ðə dɑɹlɪŋ ɡɝl kɛp seɪf."

Plainly, she had a cow's wits, too. Arymilla kept Sylvase closer than she did Elenia or Naean, and so long as she did, there was no chance that Nasin would be forced to retire from his honors. He was mad, assuredly, but sly. "I hope you're taking good care of my little Sylvase, Arymilla," he murmured. "There are fortune hunters everywhere, and I want the darling girl kept safe."

"ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ æm," ɛɹəmɪlə ɹɪplaɪd, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ oʊvɝfɛd mɛɹ pæst ɛləniə wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns. hɝ toʊn wɑz hʌniswit, ən sɪkənɪŋli doʊɾɪŋ. "ju noʊ əl kip əɹ əz seɪf əz aɪ kip maɪsɛlf." smaɪlɪŋ ðəɾ ɛmpti-hɛɾəd smaɪl, ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ næsənz kloʊk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən smuðɪŋ ɪt wɪð ði ɛɹ ə sʌmwʌn sɛɾəlɪŋ ə ʃɔl ɑn ə bɪlʌvd ɪnvʌləd. "ɪts mʌtʃ tu koʊld aʊt fəɹ ju. aɪ noʊ wʌt jə nid. ə wɔɹm tɛn ən səm hɑt spaɪst waɪn. əl bi hæpi tə hæv maɪ meɪd pɹipɛɹ ɪt fəɹ ju. ɑɹlin, əkʌmpəni lɔɹd næsən tə hɪz tɛn ən fɪks ɪm səm ɡʊd spaɪst waɪn." ə slɪm wʊmən ɪn əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ ɡeɪv ə vaɪələn twɪtʃ, ðən ɹoʊd fɔɹwɝd sloʊli, pʊʃɪŋ bæk ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ pleɪn blu kloʊk tə ɹɪvil ə pɹɪɾi feɪs ən ə tʃɹɛmjələs smaɪl. sʌɾənli ɔl lɪkspɪɾəlz ən toʊd-iɾɝz wɝ ədʒʌstɪŋ ðɛɹ kloʊks əɡɛns ðə wɪn əɹ snʌɡɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡlʌvz, lʊkɪŋ ɛniwɛɹ ɪksɛpt əɾ ɛɹəmɪləz meɪd. ɪspɛʃli ðə wɪmən. wʌn ə ðɛm cʊɾə bɪn tʃoʊzən əz izəli, ən ðeɪ nu ɪt. ɑdli, sɪlveɪs dɪd nɑt lʊk əweɪ. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl tə si hɝ feɪs ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ə hɝ hʊd, bʌt ði oʊpənɪŋ tɝn tə fɑloʊ ðə slɛndɝ wʊmən. næsənz ɡɹɪn ʃoʊɾ ɪz tiθ, meɪkɪŋ ɪm lʊk ivən mɔɹ laɪk ə ɡoʊt ðən juʒəwəl. "jɛs. jɛs, mʌld waɪn wəd bi ɡʊd. ɑɹlin, ɪz ɪt? kʌm, ɑɹlin, ðɛɹz ə ɡʊd ɡɝl. nɑt tu tʃɪl, ɑɹ ju?" ðə ɡɝl skwikt əz i swɛpt ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ soʊ kloʊs ʃi wɑz linɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəl. "jul bi wɔɹm ɪn maɪ tɛnt, aɪ pɹɑməs." wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns bæk, hi ɹoʊɾ ɔf əɾ ə wɔk, tʃɔɹɾəlɪŋ ən wɪspɝɪŋ ət ðə jʌŋ wʊmən ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. hɪz ɑɹmmɪn fɑloʊd wɪð ðə kɹik ə lɛðɝ ən ðə sloʊ, wɛt klɑp ə hʊvz ɪn ðə mʌk. wʌn ə ðɛm læft, əz ɪf ənʌðɝ hæd sɛd sʌmθɪŋ fʌni. ɛləniə ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst. pʊʃɪŋ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə næsən tə dɪstʃɹækt ɪm wɑz wʌn θɪŋ - ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv tə bi ðət pɹɪɾi; ɛni wʊmən ði oʊl ful kəd kɔɹnɝ wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ - bʌt juzɪŋ jəɹ oʊn meɪd wɑz ɹivoʊltɪŋ. nɑɾ əz ɹivoʊltɪŋ əz næsən hɪmsɛlf, ðoʊ. "ju pɹɑməs tə kip ɪm əweɪ fɹəm mi, ɛɹəmɪlə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ, taɪt vɔɪs. ðət lɛtʃɝəs oʊl kɹækbɹeɪn maɪɾ əv fɝɡɑɾən əɹ ɛɡzɪstəns fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, bʌɾ i wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə nɛks taɪm i sɔ hɝ. "ju pɹɑməs tə kip ɪm ɑkjəpaɪd."

"Of course, I am," Arymilla replied, brushing her overfed mare past Elenia without so much as a glance. Her tone was honeysweet, and sickeningly doting. "You know I'll keep her as safe as I keep myself." Smiling that empty-headed smile, she set about straightening Nasin's cloak on his shoulders and smoothing it with the air of someone settling a shawl on a beloved invalid. "It's much too cold out for you. I know what you need. A warm tent and some hot spiced wine. I'll be happy to have my maid prepare it for you. Arlene, accompany Lord Nasin to his tent and fix him some good spiced wine." A slim woman in her entourage gave a violent twitch, then rode forward slowly, pushing back the hood of her plain blue cloak to reveal a pretty face and a tremulous smile. Suddenly all lickspittles and toad-eaters were adjusting their cloaks against the wind or snugging their gloves, looking anywhere except at Arymilla's maid. Especially the women. One of them could have been chosen as easily, and they knew it. Oddly, Sylvase did not look away. It was impossible to see her face in the shadows of her hood, but the opening turned to follow the slender woman. Nasin's grin showed his teeth, making him look even more like a goat than usual. "Yes. Yes, mulled wine would be good. Arlene, is it? Come, Arlene, there's a good girl. Not too chill, are you?" The girl squeaked as he swept a corner of his cloak around her shoulders and gathered her so close she was leaning out of her saddle. "You'll be warm in my tent, I promise." Without so much as a glance back, he rode off at a walk, chortling and whispering at the young woman under his arm. His armsmen followed with the creak of leather and the slow, wet clop of hooves in the muck. One of them laughed, as if another had said something funny. Elenia shook her head in disgust. Pushing a pretty woman in front of Nasin to distract him was one thing - she did not even have to be that pretty; any woman the old fool could corner was in danger - but using your own maid was revolting. Not as revolting as Nasin himself, though. "You promised to keep him away from me, Arymilla," she said in a low, tight voice. That lecherous old crackbrain might have forgotten her existence for the moment, but he would remember the next time he saw her. "You promised to keep him occupied."

ɛɹəmɪləz feɪs ɡɹu sʌlən, ən ʃi pətʃələnli tʌɡd əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz taɪɾɝ. ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɑɾən wʌt ʃi wɑntəd. ðət wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt sɪn, tə hɝ. "ɪf jə wɑnə bi seɪf fɹəm ədmaɪɹɝz, jə ɔt tə steɪ kloʊs tə mi ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wɑndɝɪŋ əbaʊt lus. kən aɪ hɛlp ɪɾ ɪf jə ətʃɹæk mɛn? ən aɪ dɪd ɹɛskju ju. aɪ hævən hɝɾ ɛni θæŋks fəɹ ðæt."

Arymilla's face grew sullen, and she petulantly tugged her riding gloves tighter. She had not gotten what she wanted. That was a great sin, to her. "If you want to be safe from admirers, you ought to stay close to me instead of wandering about loose. Can I help it if you attract men? And I did rescue you. I haven't heard any thanks for that."

ɛləniəz dʒɔ klɛntʃt soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪt bɪɡæn tə eɪk. pɹitɛndɪŋ ðət ʃi səpɔɹɾəd ðɪs wʊmən ə hɝ oʊn tʃɔɪs wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ wɑnə baɪt sʌmθɪŋ. hɝ tʃɔɪsəz hæd bɪn meɪd klɪɹ ɪnʌf; ɹaɪt tə dʒɑɝɪɾ əɹ ɛndʒjʊɹ ən ɪkstɛndəd hʌnimun wɪð əɹ "bɪtʃɹɑθd." laɪt, ʃi maɪɾ əv teɪkən ðə tʃɔɪs ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə sɝɾənti ðət næsən wəd lɑk əɹ ʌp ɪn səm aʊt-ʌv-ðə-weɪ mænɝ ænd, æftɝ ʃi hæd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪz pɔɪŋ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli fɝɡɛt ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ. ən liv əɹ ðɛɹ. ɛɹəmɪlə ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ðə pɹitɛns, ðoʊ. ʃi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz, səm ə ðɛm ʌɾɝli ɪnsʌfɝəbəl.

Elenia's jaw clenched so hard that it began to ache. Pretending that she supported this woman of her own choice was enough to make her want to bite something. Her choices had been made clear enough; write to Jarid or endure an extended honeymoon with her "betrothed." Light, she might have taken the choice if not for the certainty that Nasin would lock her up in some out-of-the-way manor and, after she had put up with his pawing, eventually forget she was there. And leave her there. Arymilla insisted on the pretense, though. She insisted on a great many things, some of them utterly insufferable.

jɛt ðeɪ hæd tə bi sʌfɝd. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. pɝhæps, wʌns mæɾɝz wɝ sɛt stʃɹeɪt, mæstɝ laʊnɔl kəɾ ɔfɝ ɪz ətɛnʃənz tə ɛɹəmɪlə fəɹ ə fju deɪz. fɹəm sʌmwɛɹ ʃi sʌmən ən əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk smaɪl, ən meɪd hɝsɛlf bɛn əɹ nɛk əz ɪf ʃi wɝ wʌn ə ðə but-lɪkɪŋ litʃɪz u wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ ævədli. æftɝ ɔl, ɪf ʃi kɹɔl fəɹ ɛɹəmɪlə, ɪɾ oʊnli pɹuv ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt tə. ðə fil ə ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn əɹ meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə beɪð. duɪŋ ðɪs ɪn fɹʌn ə nɑiən meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə ʃɹik. "aɪ ɔfɝ jə ɔl ðə ɡɹæɾətud ðæts ɪn mi, ɛɹəmɪlə." wɛl, ðət wɑz noʊ laɪ. ɔl ðə ɡɹæɾətud ðət wɑz ɪn əɹ keɪm əbaʊɾ ikwəl tə ə dɪzaɪɝ tə stʃɹæŋɡəl ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. vɛɹi sloʊli. ʃi hæd tə ɪnheɪl dipli bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɡɛt ðə nɛks pɑɹɾ aʊt, ðoʊ. "ju mʌs fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ biɪŋ sloʊ, pliz." ə vɛɹi bɪɾɝ wɝd. "næsən meɪd mi kwaɪt dɪstʃɹɔt. jə noʊ haʊ dʒɑɝɪd wəd ɹiækt ɪf i lɝn ə næsənz bɪheɪvjɝ." hɝ oʊn vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ə hoʊn ɛdʒ ət ðət læst, bʌt ðə ful wʊmən ɡɪɡəld. ʃi ɡɪɡəld! "ʌv kɔɹs jəɹ fɝɡɪvən, ɛləniə," ʃi læft, hɝ feɪs laɪɾənɪŋ. "ɔl jə nid də ɪz æsk. dʒɑɝɪɾ ɪz ə hʌðhɛd, ɪzən hi?

Yet they had to be suffered. For the time being. Perhaps, once matters were set straight, Master Lounalt could offer his attentions to Arymilla for a few days. From somewhere she summoned an apologetic smile, and made herself bend her neck as if she were one of the boot-licking leeches who were watching her avidly. After all, if she crawled for Arymilla, it only proved they were right to. The feel of their eyes on her made her want to bathe. Doing this in front of Naean made her want to shriek. "I offer you all the gratitude that's in me, Arymilla." Well, that was no lie. All the gratitude that was in her came about equal to a desire to strangle the other woman. Very slowly. She had to inhale deeply before she could get the next part out, though. "You must forgive me for being slow, please." A very bitter word. "Nasin made me quite distraught. You know how Jarid would react if he learned of Nasin's behavior." Her own voice took on a honed edge at that last, but the fool woman giggled. She giggled! "Of course you're forgiven, Elenia," she laughed, her face lightening. "All you need do is ask. Jarid is a hothead, isn't he?

jə mʌst ɹaɪt tə hɪm ən tɛl ɪm haʊ kɑntɛn jə ɑɹ. jə ɑɹ kɑntɛnt, ɑɹən ju? jə kən dɪkteɪt tə maɪ sɛkɹətɛɹi. aɪ də heɪt steɪnɪŋ maɪ fɪŋɡɝz wɪð ɪŋk, doʊn ju?"

You must write to him and tell him how content you are. You are content, aren't you? You can dictate to my secretary. I do hate staining my fingers with ink, don't you?"

"sɝɾənli ɪm kɑntɛnt, ɛɹəmɪlə. haʊ kəɾ aɪ nɑt bi?" smaɪlɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝd noʊ ɛfɝɾ əɾ ɔl, ðɪs taɪm. ðə wʊmən æktʃəli  θɔt ʃi wɑz klɛvɝ. juzɪŋ ɛɹəmɪləz sɛkɹətɛɹi pɹɪkluɾɪd ɛni pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv sikɹəɾ ɪŋks, bʌt ʃi kəd tɛl dʒɑɝɪd kwaɪɾ oʊpənli tə də æbsəlutli nʌθɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ əɹ kaʊnsəl, ən ðə bɹeɪnləs flʌf wəd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz oʊnli oʊbeɪɪŋ.

"Certainly I'm content, Arymilla. How could I not be?" Smiling required no effort at all, this time. The woman actually thought she was clever. Using Arymilla's secretary precluded any possibility of secret inks, but she could tell Jarid quite openly to do absolutely nothing without her counsel, and the brainless fluff would think she was only obeying.

nɑɾɪŋ wɪð ə smʌɡ sɛlf-sæɾəsfækʃən, ɛɹəmɪlə ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz, ɪməteɪɾɪd baɪ hɝ koʊɾɝi. ɪf ʃi stʌk ə pɑɾ ɑn əɹ hɛɾ ən kɔld ɪɾ ə hæt, ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl wɛɹ pɑts, tu. "ɪɾ ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪt," ʃi sɛd, "æn aɪ wɑn ən ɝli stɑɹɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. æɛdɛl bɛɹɪnz kʊk əz ən ɛksələn ɹipəst weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ʌs.

Nodding with a smug self-satisfaction, Arymilla gathered her reins, imitated by her coterie. If she stuck a pot on her head and called it a hat, they would all wear pots, too. "It is getting late," she said, "and I want an early start in the morning. Aedelle Baryn's cook has an excellent repast waiting on us.

jə ən nɑiən mʌst ɹaɪd wɪð mi, ɛləniə." ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊn əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ hɑn ɔɹɪŋ ðɛm, ən ðeɪ hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs ɪksɛp tə bɪheɪv əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ, fɔlɪŋ ɪn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ. "æn sɪlveɪs, ʌv kɔɹs. kʌm, sɪlveɪs."

You and Naean must ride with me, Elenia." She made it sound as though she were hon oring them, and they had no choice except to behave as though she were, falling in on either side of her. "And Sylvase, of course. Come, Sylvase."

næsənz ɡɹændɔɾɝ bɹɔɾ əɹ mɛɹ kloʊsɝ, bʌt nɑɾ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɛɹəmɪlə. ʃi fɑloʊɾ ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪnd, wɪð ɛɹəmɪləz sɪkɑfæns kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ hilz sɪns ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ɪnvaɪɾəd tə ɹaɪd wɪð ɛɹəmɪlə. dɪspaɪt ðə fɪtfəl, aɪsi wɪn tʌɡɪŋ ət ðɛɹ kloʊks, sɛvɹəl ə ðə wɪmən ən tu əɹ θɹi ʌv ðə mɛn tʃɹaɪɾ ʌnsəksɛsfəli tə ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðə ɡɝl ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ʃi sɛldəm sɛd tu wɝdz təɡɛðɝ.

Nasin's granddaughter brought her mare closer, but not up beside Arymilla. She followed a little behind, with Arymilla's sycophants crowding on her heels since they had not been invited to ride with Arymilla. Despite the fitful, icy wind tugging at their cloaks, several of the women and two or three of the men tried unsuccessfully to engage the girl in conversation. She seldom said two words together.

stɪl, wɪð noʊ haɪ siɾ ɪn ɹitʃ tə fɔn oʊvɝ, ə haɪ sits ɛɹ wəd du, ən meɪbi wʌn ə ðə fɛloʊz hoʊp tə mɛɹi wɛl. laɪkli wʌn əɹ tu wɝ mɔɹ ɪn ðə neɪtʃɝ ʌv ɡɑɹdz, əɹ ət list spaɪz meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə kəmjunəkeɪt wɪð ɛniwʌn ɪn əɹ haʊs. ðɪs lɑt wəd faɪn ðəɾ ɪksaɪɾɪŋ, tʌtʃɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒəz ə paʊɝ. ɛləniə hæɾ əɹ oʊn plænz fəɹ sɪlveɪs. ɛɹəmɪlə wɑz ənʌðɝ wɪð noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə næɾɝɪŋ əweɪ wən ɛniwʌn wɪð sɛns wəd bi mʌfəlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn əɹ kaʊl, ən əɹ tʃæɾɝ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu ðə daɪɪŋ laɪt flɪɾɪd fɹəm wʌt lɝz sɪstɝ wəɾ ɔfɝ ət sʌpɝ tə ðə plænz fəɹ əɹ kɔɹəneɪʃən. ɛləniə lɪsən oʊnli ɪnʌf tə mɝmɝ əpɹuvɪŋli ət wʌt simd əpɹoʊpɹiət spɑts. ɪf ðə ful wɑntəd tə ɔfɝ ə swɔɹn æmnəsti tə ðoʊz u əpoʊz hɝ, fɑɹ bi ɪt fɹəm ɛləniə sɑɝən tə tɛl əɹ ʃi wɑz ə ful. ɪt wɑz peɪnfəl ɪnʌf hævɪŋ tə . . . sɪmpɝ. . . ət ðə wʊmən wɪθaʊt lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ. ðən wʌn θɪŋ ɛɹəmɪlə sɛd hɪɾ əɹ ɪɹ laɪk ən ɔl.

Still, with no High Seat in reach to fawn over, a High Seat's heir would do, and maybe one of the fellows hoped to marry well. Likely one or two were more in the nature of guards, or at least spies making sure she did not try to communicate with anyone in her House. This lot would find that exciting, touching on the edges of power. Elenia had her own plans for Sylvase. Arymilla was another with no objections to nattering away when anyone with sense would be muffling herself in her cowl, and her chatter as they rode through the dying light flitted from what Lir's sister would offer at supper to the plans for her coronation. Elenia listened only enough to murmur approvingly at what seemed appropriate spots. If the fool wanted to offer a sworn amnesty to those who opposed her, far be it from Elenia Sarand to tell her she was a fool. It was painful enough having to . . . simper. . . at the woman without listening to her. Then one thing Arymilla said hit her ear like an awl.

"ju ən nɑiən woʊn maɪnd ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛd, wɪl ju? ɪt simz wəɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə disən tɛns hɪɹ." ʃi flɪɾɪd ɑn, bʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɛləniə kəd nɑt hɪɹ ə wɝd. ʃi fɛlt əz ðoʊ hɝ skɪn hæd bɪn stʌft wɪð snoʊ. tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, ʃi mɛt nɑiənz ʃɑkt ɡeɪz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑsəbəl weɪ ɛɹəmɪlə kəd noʊ əbaʊt ðɛɹ tʃæns miɾɪŋ, nɑt jɛt, ən ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd, waɪ wəd ʃi ɔfɝ əm ə tʃæns tə plɑt təɡɛðɝ? ə tʃɹæp? spaɪz tə lɪsən tə wʌt ðeɪ sɛd? nɑiənz meɪd, ɔɹ. . . .

"You and Naean won't mind sharing a bed, will you? It seems we are short of decent tents here." She flitted on, but for a moment, Elenia could not hear a word. She felt as though her skin had been stuffed with snow. Turning her head slightly, she met Naean's shocked gaze. There was no possible way Arymilla could know about their chance meeting, not yet, and even if she did, why would she offer them a chance to plot together? A trap? Spies to listen to what they said? Naean's maid, or. . . .

əɹ dʒæni? ðə wɝl sim tə spɪn. blæk ən sɪlvɝ flɛks floʊɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛləniəz aɪz. ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə feɪnt. əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛɹəmɪlə hæɾ ədʒɹɛst sʌmθɪŋ tə hɝ dɝɛkli ən wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ən ænsɝ wɪð ən ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪmpeɪʃən skaʊl. fɹæntəkəli, ʃi kæst əɹ maɪn əbaʊt. jɛs, ʃi hæɾ ɪt. "ə ɡɪldɪd koʊtʃ, ɛɹəmɪlə?" wʌɾ ə ɹɪdɪkjələs noʊʃən. əz wɛl ɹaɪɾ ɪn ə tɪŋkɝz wæɡən! "oʊ, dɪlaɪtfəl! jə də hæv sətʃ mɑɹvələs aɪdiəz!" ɛɹəmɪləz pliz sɪmpɝ pʊɾ ə lɪɾəl iz ɪndə ɛləniəz bɹiðɪŋ. ðə wʊmən wɑz ə bɹeɪnləs ful. meɪbi ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɔɹɾədʒ ə suɾəbəl tɛns. mɔɹ laɪkli ʃi dʒʌs θɔt ðeɪ wɝ seɪf, naʊ.

Or Janny? The world seemed to spin. Black and silver flecks floated in front of Elenia's eyes. She thought she was about to faint. Abruptly she realized that Arymilla had addressed something to her directly and was waiting on an answer with an increasingly impatient scowl. Frantically, she cast her mind about. Yes, she had it. "A gilded coach, Arymilla?" What a ridiculous notion. As well ride in a Tinker's wagon! "Oh, delightful! You do have such marvelous ideas!" Arymilla's pleased simper put a little ease into Elenia's breathing. The woman was a brainless fool. Maybe there was a shortage of suitable tents. More likely she just thought they were safe, now.

teɪmd. ɛləniə tɝn əɹ bɛɹd tiθ ɪndə ə sɪmpɝ ə hɝ oʊn. bʌt ʃi pʊɾ əsaɪɾ ɛni aɪdiə ʌv hævɪŋ ðə tæɹɑbənɝ "ɛntɝteɪn" ðə wʊmən, ivən fəɹ ən aʊɝ. wɪð dʒɑɝɪdz sɪɡnətʃɝ ɑn ðət plɛdʒ, ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə klɪɹ əɹ pæθ tə ðə θɹoʊn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɪn hæn ən ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd. ði oʊnli kwɛstʃən wɑz wɛðɝ ɛɹəmɪlə əɹ næsən ʃəd daɪ fɝst.

Tamed. Elenia turned her bared teeth into a simper of her own. But she put aside any idea of having the Taraboner "entertain" the woman, even for an hour. With Jarid's signature on that pledge, there was only one way to clear her path to the throne. Everything was in hand and ready to go forward. The only question was whether Arymilla or Nasin should die first.

naɪt pɹɛs daʊn ɑn keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ə hɑɹd koʊl dʒɹɪvən dip baɪ ʃɑɹp wɪnz. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə ɡloʊ ʌv laɪt spɪlɪŋ fɹəm ən ʌpɝ wɪndoʊ spoʊk ə pipəl stɪl əweɪk, bʌt moʊst ʃʌɾɝz wɝ dʒɹɔn, ən ə θɪn slɪvɝ ə mun loʊ ɪn ðə skaɪ oʊnli sim tə ɛmfəsaɪz ðə dɑɹknəs. ivən ðə snoʊ koʊɾɪŋ ɹuftɑps ən paɪld əlɔŋ ðə fɹʌns ə bɪldɪŋz wɛɹ ɪt hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðə deɪz tʃɹæfɪk wɑz ə ʃæɾoʊi ɡɹeɪ. ðə loʊn mæn mʌfəl hɛd tə æŋkəlz ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə fɹoʊzən slʌʃ lɛft ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ænsɝd tə dɑv hænlən əɹ dɔɪlən mɛlɝ wɪð ikwəl iz; ə neɪm wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə koʊt, ən ə mæn tʃeɪnʒd ɪz koʊt wɛnɛvɝ niɾəd. hi hæd wɔɹn ə nʌmbɝ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz. ɡɪvən ɪz wɪʃɪz, hi wʊɾə hæɾ ɪz fiɾ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə ɹɔɹɪŋ faɪɝ ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, ə mʌɡ ɪn ɪz hænd, ə pɪtʃɝ ə bɹændi əɾ ɪz saɪd, ən ə wɪlɪŋ wɛnk ɑn ɪz ni, bʌɾ i hæɾ ʌðɝz' wɪʃɪz tə sɝv. ət lis ðə fʊɾɪŋ wɑz bɛɾɝ hɪɹ ɪn ðə nu sɪɾi. nɑt ɡʊd, wɪð ðɪs fɹoʊzən mʌk ʌndɝfʊt ðət kəd tɝn ə kɛɹləs stɛp ɪndə ə spɹɔl, jɛɾ ə mænz buts wɝ lɛs laɪkli tə ɡoʊ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪm hɪɹ ðən bæk ɑn ðə stipɝ hɪlz ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. bɪsaɪdz, dɑɹknəs suɾəd ɪm tənaɪt.

Night pressed down on Caemlyn with a hard cold driven deep by sharp winds. Here and there a glow of light spilling from an upper window spoke of people still awake, but most shutters were drawn, and a thin sliver of moon low in the sky only seemed to emphasize the darkness. Even the snow coating rooftops and piled along the fronts of buildings where it had escaped the day's traffic was a shadowy gray. The lone man muffled head to ankles in a dark cloak, striding through the frozen slush left on the paving stones, answered to Daved Hanlon or Doilan Mellar with equal ease; a name was no more than a coat, and a man changed his coat whenever needed. He had worn a number over the years. Given his wishes, he would have had his feet up in front of a roaring fire in the Royal Palace, a mug in his hand, a pitcher of brandy at his side, and a willing wench on his knee, but he had others' wishes to serve. At least the footing was better here in the New City. Not good, with this frozen muck underfoot that could turn a careless step into a sprawl, yet a man's boots were less likely to go out from under him here than back on the steeper hills of the Inner City. Besides, darkness suited him tonight.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn fju pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits wən i stɑɹɾəd aʊt, ən ðə nʌmbɝ hæd dwɪndəld əweɪ əz dɑɹknəs dipənd. waɪz pipəl steɪɾ ɪndɔɹz wʌns naɪt fɛl. əkeɪʒənəli, dɪm ʃeɪps skʌlkt ɪn ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz, bʌɾ æftɝ ə bɹif stʌɾi ʌv hænlən, ðeɪ skʌɾəld ɝaʊn kɔɹnɝz əhɛɾ ə hɪm, əɹ wɪθdʒɹu ɪndə æliz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mʌfəl ðɛɹ kɝsɪz əz ðeɪ flaʊndɝɾ ɪn snoʊ ðət laɪkli hæd nɑt bɪn tʌtʃt baɪ ðə sʌn. hi wɑz nɑt bʌlki, ən lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən ði ævɝɪdʒ ɹʌn ə mɛn, wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪt hɪɾən baɪ hɪz kloʊk tə but, bʌt fʊtpædz lʊk fəɹ wiknəs əɹ hɛzəteɪʃən, ən i muvd wɪð ən ɑbviəs sɛlf-kɑnfəɾəns, pleɪnli ʌnəfɹeɪɾ ə lɝkɝz. ən æɾətud hɛlp baɪ ðə lɔŋ dæɡɝ kənsild ɪn ɪz ɡɔntələɾəd ɹaɪt hænd.

There had been few people in the streets when he started out, and the number had dwindled away as darkness deepened. Wise people stayed indoors once night fell. Occasionally, dim shapes skulked in the deeper shadows, but after a brief study of Hanlon, they scuttled around corners ahead of him, or withdrew into alleys trying to muffle their curses as they floundered in snow that likely had not been touched by the sun. He was not bulky, and little taller than the average run of men, with his sword and breastplate hidden by his cloak to boot, but footpads looked for weakness or hesitation, and he moved with an obvious self-confidence, plainly unafraid of lurkers. An attitude helped by the long dagger concealed in his gauntleted right hand.

hi kɛpt ən aɪ aʊt fəɹ pətʃɹoʊlz ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn əz i wɔkt, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə si ɛni. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz ən pɹaʊlɝz wʊɾə sɔɾ ʌðɝ hʌntɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ əbaʊt. ʌv kɔɹs, hi kəd sɛnd noʊzi ɡɑɹdzmɪn ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ wɪð ə wɝd, jɛɾ i wɑntəd noʊ əbzɝvɝz ʌv ɛni kaɪnd, ən noʊ kwɛstʃənz waɪ hi wɑz soʊ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə pæləs əfʊt. hɪz stɛp hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz tu hɛvəli kloʊkt wɪmən əpɪɹɾ əɾ ə kɹɔsɪŋ wɛl əhɛd, bʌt ðeɪ muvd ɑn wɪθaʊt ɡlænsɪŋ ɪz weɪ, ən i bɹið mɔɹ izəli. vɛɹi fju wɪmən wəd vɛntʃɝ aʊɾ ət ðɪs taɪm ə naɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə mæn əlɔŋ tə wil sɔɹɾ əɹ kʌdʒəl, ən ivən wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz i wʊɾə weɪdʒɝɾ ə fɪsfəl ʌv ɡoʊl tə ə hɔɹs æpəl ðət pɛɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. əɹ ɛls səm ə ðoʊz stʃɹeɪnʒ wɪmən u fɪl moʊst ə ðə bɛdz ɪn ðə pæləs.

He kept an eye out for patrols of Guardsmen as he walked, but he did not expect to see any. The strongarms and prowlers would have sought other hunting grounds if the Guards were about. Of course, he could send nosy Guardsmen on their way with a word, yet he wanted no observers of any kind, and no questions why he was so far from the palace afoot. His step hesitated as two heavily cloaked women appeared at a crossing well ahead, but they moved on without glancing his way, and he breathed more easily. Very few women would venture out at this time of night without a man along to wield sword or cudgel, and even without seeing their faces he would have wagered a fistful of gold to a horse apple that pair were Aes Sedai. Or else some of those strange women who filled most of the beds in the palace.

ðə θɔɾ ə ðət lɑt bɹɔɾ ə skaʊl, ən ə pɹɪklɪŋ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz laɪk ðə bɹʌʃ ə nɛɾəlz. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə pæləs, ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɪm ðə ɡɹɪps. ðə si foʊk wɪmən wɝ bæɾ ɪnʌf, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ wɛn sweɪɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə hɔlz ɪn ðət sɪdʌktɪv weɪ, ðən pʊld ə naɪf ɑn ə mæn. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən θɔɾ ə pæɾɪŋ wʌn ɑn ðə bɑɾəm æftɝ i ɹilaɪz ðeɪ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk stʃɹeɪnʒ kæts ɪn ə bɑks. ən pleɪnli, haʊɛvɝ ɪmpɑsəbli, ðə si foʊk wɝ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ kæts. ði ʌðɝz wɝ wɝs, ɪn ə weɪ. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə ɹumɝz sɛd, hi nu ðə lʊk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ɪt dɪd nɑɾ ɪnklud ɹɪŋkəlz. jɛt səm ə ðɛm kəd tʃænəl, ən i hæd ðə dɪstɝbɪŋ noʊʃən ðət ðeɪ ɔl kʊd.

The thought of that lot brought a scowl, and a prickling between his shoulder blades like the brush of nettles. Whatever was going on in the palace, it was enough to give him the grips. The Sea Folk women were bad enough, and not just because they went swaying along the halls in that seductive way, then pulled a knife on a man. He had not even thought of patting one on the bottom after he realized they and the Aes Sedai were staring at one another like strange cats in a box. And plainly, however impossibly, the Sea Folk were the larger cats. The others were worse, in a way. No matter what the rumors said, he knew the look of Aes Sedai, and it did not include wrinkles. Yet some of them could channel, and he had the disturbing notion that they all could.

wɪtʃ meɪd noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl. meɪbi ðə si foʊk hæd səm sɔɹɾ ə pəkjuljɝ dɪspənseɪʃən, bʌɾ əz fəɹ ðiz kɪn, əz fæljən kɔl ðɛm, ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðəɾ ɪf θɹi wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl ən wɝ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ sæt daʊn ət ðə seɪm teɪbəl, ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ əpɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd fɪnɪʃ ə pɪtʃɝ ʌv waɪn ən tɛl əm tə muv ɑn ən nɛvɝ spik tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əɡɛn. ən meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪt, bɪsaɪdz.

Which made no sense at all. Maybe the Sea Folk had some sort of peculiar dispensation, but as for these Kin, as Falion called them, everyone knew that if three women who could channel and were not Aes Sedai sat down at the same table, Aes Sedai would appear before they could finish a pitcher of wine and tell them to move on and never speak to one another again. And make sure they did it, besides.

ðət wɑz ɡɪvən. bʌt ðəɹ ðoʊz wɪmən sæɾ ɪn ðə pæləs, oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ pɹaɪvət miɾɪŋz, wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪθaʊt wʌn fɹaʊn bɪtwin ðɛm. əntɪl tədeɪ, ɛniweɪ, ən wʌtɛvɝ hæd sɛɾ əm hʌɾəlɪŋ laɪk fɹaɪɾənd hɛnz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz æŋkʃəs. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni ɑɾətiz tə sut hɪm. wən ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪheɪvd ɑdli, ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ə mæn tə lʊk tə ðə seɪfti ʌv ɪz oʊn skɪn. wɪð ə kɝs i dʒɝk hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə hɪz ɹɛvɝi. ə mæn niɾəd tə lʊk aʊt fəɹ ɪz skɪn ɪn ðə naɪt, tu, ən lɛɾɪŋ ɪz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən dʒɹɪft wɑz noʊ weɪ tə də ɪt. ət list i hæd nɑt stɑpt, əɹ ivən sloʊd. æftɝ ə fju mɔɹ stɛps, hi smaɪld ə θɪn smaɪl ən θʌm ðə bleɪɾ ə hɪz dæɡɝ. ðə wɪn saɪd daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ ən fɛl, wɪsəld əkɹɔs ɹuftɑps ən fɛl, ən ɪn ðə bɹif saɪlənsɪz bɪtwin i kəd hɪɹ ðə feɪn kɹʌntʃ ə ðə buts ðət hæd bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm sɪns ʃɔɹtli æftɝ i lɛf ðə pæləs. ət ðə nɛks kɹɔsɪŋ stʃɹit, hi tɝn tə hɪz ɹaɪɾ ət ðə seɪm stɛɾi ənhɝid peɪs, ðən sʌɾənli flæɾənd ɪz bæk əɡɛns ðə fɹʌn ʌv ə steɪbəl ðət stʊd hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ. ðə waɪd steɪbəl dɔɹz wɝ ʃʌt, ən laɪkli bɑɹɾ ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd, bʌt ðə smɛl ə hɔɹs ən hɔɹs dʌŋ hʌŋ ɪn ði aɪsi ɛɹ. ði ɪn əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit wɑz kloʊzd ʌp taɪt, əz wɛl, ɪts wɪndoʊz ʃʌɾɝd ən dɑɹk, ði oʊnli saʊn əsaɪd fɹəm ðə wɪn ðə kɹik ʌv ɪts swɪŋɪŋ saɪn i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. noʊ wʌn tə si wʌt ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt.

That was given. But there those women sat in the palace, over a hundred of them, holding their private meetings, walking around Aes Sedai without one frown between them. Until today, anyway, and whatever had set them huddling like frightened hens, the Aes Sedai had been every bit as anxious. There were too many oddities to suit him. When Aes Sedai behaved oddly, it was time for a man to look to the safety of his own skin. With a curse he jerked himself out of his reverie. A man needed to look out for his skin in the night, too, and letting his concentration drift was no way to do it. At least he had not stopped, or even slowed. After a few more steps, he smiled a thin smile and thumbed the blade of his dagger. The wind sighed down the street and fell, whistled across rooftops and fell, and in the brief silences between he could hear the faint crunch of the boots that had been following him since shortly after he left the palace. At the next crossing street, he turned to his right at the same steady unhurried pace, then suddenly flattened his back against the front of a stable that stood hard on the corner. The wide stable doors were shut, and likely barred on the inside, but the smell of horse and horse dung hung in the icy air. The inn across the street was closed up tight, as well, its windows shuttered and dark, the only sound aside from the wind the creak of its swinging sign he could not make out in the night. No one to see what they should not.

hi hæɾ ə moʊməns wɔɹnɪŋ, ðə saʊn ə buts kwɪkən ɪn ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə lɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə saɪt tu lɔŋ, ən ðən ə kaʊl hɛd wɑz θɹʌs kɔʃəsli ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ. nɑt kɔʃəsli ɪnʌf, ʌv kɔɹs. hɪz lɛf hæn dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə kaʊl tə siz ə θɹoʊɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm ɪz ɹaɪt meɪɾ ə pɹæktəst stɑp-θɹʌst wɪð ðə dæɡɝ. hi hæf ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ə bɹɛstpleɪt, əɹ ə meɪl ʃɝɾ ʌndɝ ðə mænz koʊt, ən i wɑz ɹɛɾi ɪf i dɪd, bʌɾ ən ɪntʃ ə stil sæŋk izəli bɪniθ ðə fɛloʊz bɹɛstboʊn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ ðət sim tə pɛɹəlaɪz ə mænz lʌŋz, soʊ hi kəd nɑt kɹaɪ aʊt, əntɪl i hæd dʒɹaʊn ɪn ɪz oʊn blʌd, bʌɾ i nu ðəɾ ɪt dɪd. stɪl, tənaɪɾ i hæd noʊ taɪm tə weɪt. noʊ ɡɑɹdz ɪn saɪɾ ət pɹɛzən dɪd nɑt min mæɾɝz wəd steɪ ðət weɪ fəɹ lɔŋ. wɪð ə kwɪk ɹɛntʃ, hi slæm ðə mænz hɛɾ əɡɛns ðə steɪbəlz stoʊn wɔl hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə kɹæk ə skʌl, ðən ʃʌvd ɪz dæɡɝ tə ðə hɪlt, filɪŋ ðə bleɪd ɡɹeɪɾ əz ɪt dʌɡ θɹu ðə fɛloʊz spaɪn.

He had a moment's warning, the sound of boots quickened in an effort not to let him out of sight too long, and then a cowled head was thrust cautiously around the corner. Not cautiously enough, of course. His left hand darted into the cowl to seize a throat at the same time his right made a practiced stop-thrust with the dagger. He half expected to find a breastplate, or a mail shirt under the man's coat, and he was ready if he did, but an inch of steel sank easily beneath the fellow's breastbone. He did not know why that seemed to paralyze a man's lungs, so he could not cry out, until he had drowned in his own blood, but he knew that it did. Still, tonight he had no time to wait. No Guards in sight at present did not mean matters would stay that way for long. With a quick wrench, he slammed the man's head against the stable's stone wall hard enough to crack a skull, then shoved his dagger to the hilt, feeling the blade grate as it dug through the fellow's spine.
