hɪz bɹiðɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn stɛɾi - kɪlɪŋ wɑz dʒʌst ə θɪŋ ðæt, hæd tə bi dʌn naʊ ən əɡɛn, nʌθɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪksaɪɾəd oʊvɝ - bʌɾ i hɝidli loʊɝd ðə kɔɹps tə ðə snoʊ əɡɛns ðə wɔl ən kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪɾ ɪt, waɪpɪŋ ɪz bleɪɾ ɑn ðə dɛd mænz dɑɹk koʊt waɪl stɪkɪŋ ɪz ʌðɝ hæn ɪndə hɪz ɑɹmpɪt tə tʌɡ ɔf ɪz stilbækt ɡɔnlət. hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ, hi wɑtʃt ðə stʃɹit boʊθ weɪz əz i fɛl kwɪkli əkɹɔs ðə mænz feɪs ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ə ɹæsp ə stʌbəl ʌndɝ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz toʊld ɪm ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə mæn, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ. mæn, wʊmən əɹ tʃaɪl meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns tə hɪm - fulz bɪheɪvd əz ðoʊ tʃɪlʒɹən hæd noʊ aɪz tə si əɹ tʌŋz tə tɛl wʌt ðeɪ sɔ - jɛɾ i wɪʃt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə mʌstæʃ əɹ ə bʌlbəs noʊz, ɛniθɪŋ tə spɑɹk ə mɛmɹi ən tɛl ɪm u ðɪs fɛloʊ hæd bɪn. ə skwiz ət ðə dɛd mænz sliv faʊn θɪk wʊl, niðɝ faɪn nɔɹ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɹʌf, ən ə sɪnjui ɑɹm ðət cʊɾə bɪlɔŋ tə klɝk əɹ wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ əɹ fʊtmən. tə ɛni mæn, ɪn ʃɔɹt, dʒʌs laɪk ðə koʊt. sɝtʃɪŋ daʊn ðə bɑɾi, hi ɹaɪfəl θɹu ðə fɛloʊz pɑkəts, faɪndɪŋ ə wʊɾən koʊm ən ə bɔl ə twaɪn, wɪtʃ i tɔst əsaɪd. ət ðə mænz bɛlt, hɪz hæn pɔzd. ə lɛðɝ ʃiθ hʌŋ ðɛɹ, ɛmpti. noʊ mæn ɑn ɝθ cʊɾə dʒɹɔn ə dæɡɝ æftɝ hænlənz bleɪd faʊn ɪz lʌŋz. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ɡʊd kɑz fəɹ ə mæn tə kæɹi hɪz naɪf ənʃiðd wən i wɔkt aʊɾ ət naɪt, bʌt ðə ɹizən ðət keɪm moʊst ɹɛɾəli tə maɪn ɹaɪt ðən wɑz tə stæb sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə bæk əɹ kʌɾ ə θɹoʊt. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fliɾɪŋ pɔz, ðoʊ.

His breathing remained steady - killing was just a thing that, had to be done now and again, nothing to get excited over - but he hurriedly lowered the corpse to the snow against the wall and crouched beside it, wiping his blade on the dead man's dark coat while sticking his other hand into his armpit to tug off his steelbacked gauntlet. Head swiveling, he watched the street both ways as he felt quickly across the man's face in the darkness. A rasp of stubble under his fingers told him that it was a man, but no more. Man, woman or child made no difference to him - fools behaved as though children had no eyes to see or tongues to tell what they saw - yet he wished there had been a mustache or a bulbous nose, anything to spark a memory and tell him who this fellow had been. A squeeze at the dead man's sleeve found thick wool, neither fine nor particularly rough, and a sinewy arm that could have belonged to clerk or wagon driver or footman. To any man, in short, just like the coat. Searching down the body, he rifled through the fellow's pockets, finding a wooden comb and a ball of twine, which he tossed aside. At the man's belt, his hand paused. A leather sheath hung there, empty. No man on earth could have drawn a dagger after Hanlon's blade found his lungs. Of course, there was good cause for a man to carry his knife unsheathed when he walked out at night, but the reason that came most readily to mind right then was to stab someone in the back or cut a throat. It was only a fleeting pause, though.

weɪstɪŋ noʊ taɪm ɑn spɛkjəleɪʃən, hi slaɪst ɔf ðə fɛloʊz pɝs bɪniθ ðə dʒɹɔstʃɹɪŋz. ðə weɪɾ ə ðə kɔɪnz i spɪld ɪndə hɪz hæn ən heɪstəli stʌft ɪndə hɪz oʊn pɑkət toʊld ɪm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡoʊld, laɪkli nɑɾ ivən ə pis ə sɪlvɝ, bʌɾ ə kʌt pɝs ən noʊ kɔɪnz wəd meɪk huɛvɝ faʊn ðə bɑɾi θɪŋk ɪm ðə pɹeɪ ʌv stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, hi tʌɡd ɑn ɪz ɡɔnlət, ən oʊnli moʊməns æftɝ dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪz bleɪd hoʊm, hi wɑz stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə slʌʃ-kʌvɝd peɪvmənt wʌns mɔɹ, dæɡɝ hɛl kloʊs tə hɪz saɪd bɪniθ ɪz kloʊk ən aɪz wɛɹi. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪlæks əntɪl i wɑz ə stʃɹiɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɛd mæn, ən ðən i dɪd nɑt ɹɪlæks vɛɹi fɑɹ.

Wasting no time on speculation, he sliced off the fellow's purse beneath the drawstrings. The weight of the coins he spilled into his hand and hastily stuffed into his own pocket told him there was no gold, likely not even a piece of silver, but a cut purse and no coins would make whoever found the body think him the prey of strongarms. Straightening, he tugged on his gauntlet, and only moments after driving his blade home, he was striding along the slush-covered pavement once more, dagger held close to his side beneath his cloak and eyes wary. He did not relax until he was a street away from the dead man, and then he did not relax very far.

moʊs pipəl u hɝɾ ə ðə kɪlɪŋ wəɾ æksɛp ðə teɪl ə mɝɾɝ fəɹ θɛf ðəɾ i hæd leɪɾ aʊt fəɹ ðɛm, bʌt nɑt huɛvɝ hæd sɛn ðə fɛloʊ. fɑloʊɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm ðə pæləs mɛn ðəɾ i hæd bɪn sɛnt, bʌt baɪ hum? hi wɑz fɛɹli ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛni ʌv ðə si foʊk u wɑntəɾ ə naɪf pʊɾ ɪn ɪm wʊɾə dʌn ðə did hɝsɛlf. fəɹ ɔl ðət ðə kɪn tʃɹʌbəld ɪm dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ ðɛɹ, ðeɪ sim tə kip kwaɪəɾ ən wɔk smɔl. tʃɹu, pipəl u pɹæktəst əvɔɪɾɪŋ noʊɾəs wɝ ðə moʊs laɪkli tə ɹɪzɔɹt tə ə haɪɝd naɪf ɪn ðə naɪt, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd mɔɹ ðən θɹi wɝdz əɾ ə taɪm wɪð ɛni ʌv ðɛm, ən i sɝɾənli hæd nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə fɪŋɡɝ wʌn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ simd mɔɹ laɪkli, jɛɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ i hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə ɹaʊs ðɛɹ səspɪʃənz. stɪl, ɛni wʌn ə ðɛm maɪɾ əv əɹ oʊn ɹizənz fəɹ wɑntɪŋ ɪm dɛd. jə kəd nɛvɝ tɛl wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən wɑz ə sɪli bɪn u sim tə θɪŋk ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ə kɛɹɪktɝ aʊɾ ʌv ə stɔɹi, meɪbi ivən ðə ɹil bɝdʒɪt, ɪf ðəɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ə ɹil bɝdʒɪt, bʌt ʃi kəd wɛl θɪŋk i wɑz ə θɹɛt tə hɝ pəzɪʃən. ʃi maɪt bi ə stʃɹʌmpət, wɪɡəlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ɪn ðoʊz tʃɹaʊzɝz ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd, jɛt ʃi hæɾ ə koʊld aɪ. ðət wʌn kəɾ ɔɹɾɝ ə θɹoʊt slɪt wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ. ðə læs pɑsəbɪləɾi wɑz ðə wʌn ðət wɝiɾ ɪm moʊst, ðoʊ. hɪz oʊn mæstɝz wɝ nɑt ðə moʊs tʃɹʌstɪŋ ə pipəl, ən nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə moʊs tʃɹʌstwɝði. ən ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn əvɑɹhən, hu kɝənli ɡeɪv ɪm ɪz ɔɹɾɝz, wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd sɛn ə sʌmənz ðət hæd pʊld ɪm ɪndə ðə naɪt. wɛɹ ə fɛloʊ dʒʌs hæpən tə bi weɪɾɪŋ tə fɑloʊ hɪm, naɪf ɪn hænd. hi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪn koʊɪnsɪɾəns, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt pipəl sɛɾ əbaʊt ðɪs ælθɹ.

Most people who heard of the killing would accept the tale of murder for theft that he had laid out for them, but not whoever had sent the fellow. Following all the way from the palace meant that he had been sent, but by whom? He was fairly sure that any of the Sea Folk who wanted a knife put in him would have done the deed herself. For all that the Kin troubled him just by being there, they seemed to keep quiet and walk small. True, people who practiced avoiding notice were the most likely to resort to a hired knife in the night, but he had never exchanged more than three words at a time with any of them, and he certainly had never tried to finger one. The Aes Sedai seemed more likely, yet he was sure he had done nothing to rouse their suspicions. Still, any one of them might have her own reasons for wanting him dead. You could never tell with Aes Sedai. Birgitte Trahelion was a silly bint who seemed to think she really was a character out of a story, maybe even the real Birgitte, if there had ever been a real Birgitte, but she could well think he was a threat to her position. She might be a strumpet, wiggling around the corridors in those trousers the way she did, yet she had a cold eye. That one could order a throat slit without blinking. The last possibility was the one that worried him most, though. His own masters were not the most trusting of people, and not always the most trustworthy. And the Lady Shiaine Avarhin, who currently gave him his orders, was the one who had sent a summons that had pulled him into the night. Where a fellow just happened to be waiting to follow him, knife in hand. He did not believe in coincidence, no matter what people said about this al'Thor.

θɔts ə tɝnɪŋ bæk tə ðə pæləs keɪm ən wɛn ɪn ə flæʃ. hi hæd ɡoʊl tʌkt əweɪ; hi kəd bɹaɪb ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə ɡeɪts əz izəli əz ɛniwʌn ɛls, əɹ dʒʌst ɔɹɾɝ wʌn oʊpən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ ɪm ɹaɪɾ aʊt. bʌɾ ɪt wəd min spɛndɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz laɪf wɑtʃɪŋ ɪz bæk, ən ɛniwʌn u keɪm ɪnsaɪɾ ɑɹmz lɛŋθ ə hɪm maɪt bi ðə wʌn sɛn tə kɪl hɪm. nɑt soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə weɪ hi lɪv naʊ. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sɝɾənti ðət sʌmwʌn wəd pʊt pɔɪzən ɪn ɪz sup əɹ ə naɪf θɹu hɪz ɹɪbz sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ðət stoʊn-aɪd tʃɹʌl bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðə moʊs laɪkli kʌlpɹɪt. əɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. əɹ meɪbi hi hæɾ əfɛndəd ðiz kɪn sʌmhaʊ. stɪl, ɪɾ ɔlweɪz peɪd tə bi kɛɹfəl. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz flɛkst ɝaʊn ðə dæɡɝz hɪlt. laɪf wɑz ɡʊɾ ət ðə moʊmənt, wɪð plɛnti ʌv kʌmfɝɾ ən plɛnti ʌv wɪmən ɪmpɹɛst əɹ fɹaɪɾənd ɪndə kəmplaɪəns baɪ ə kæptən ə ðə ɡɑɹdz, bʌt laɪf ɑn ðə ɹʌn wɑz ɔlweɪz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə dɛθ hɪɹ ən naʊ.

Thoughts of turning back to the palace came and went in a flash. He had gold tucked away; he could bribe his way through the gates as easily as anyone else, or just order one opened long enough to let him ride out. But it would mean spending the rest of his life watching his back, and anyone who came inside arm's length of him might be the one sent to kill him. Not so different from the way he lived now. Except for the certainty that someone would put poison in his soup or a knife through his ribs sooner or later. Besides, that stone-eyed trull Birgitte was the most likely culprit. Or an Aes Sedai. Or maybe he had offended these Kin somehow. Still, it always paid to be careful. His fingers flexed around the dagger's hilt. Life was good at the moment, with plenty of comfort and plenty of women impressed or frightened into compliance by a Captain of the Guards, but life on the run was always preferable to death here and now.

faɪndɪŋ ðə kɝɛk stʃɹit, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə kɝɛk haʊs, wɑz nɑt wʌn nɛɹoʊ saɪd stʃɹit lʊk vɛɹi laɪk ənʌðɝ wən dɑɹknəs swɑð boʊθ - bʌɾ i tʊk ə kɛɹ ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli faʊn hɪmsɛlf paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə fɹʌn dɔɹz ʌv ə tɔl, ʃæɾoʊd paɪl ðət cʊɾə bɪlɔŋ tə ə wɛlθi bʌt dɪskɹit mɝtʃənt. ɪksɛpt i nu naʊ ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt. əvɑɹhən wɑz ə taɪni haʊs, ɪkstɪŋk səm sɛd, bʌt wʌn dɔɾɝ ʌv ɪt ɹɪmeɪnd, ən ʃieɪn pəzɛs mʌni. wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz swʌŋ oʊpən, ən i flʌŋ ʌp ə hæn əɡɛns ðə sʌɾən ɡlɛɹ ə laɪt. hɪz lɛf hænd; ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz ɹaɪt, hi kɛp kənsild ən ɹɛɾi. skwɪntɪŋ θɹu hɪz spɹɛd fɪŋɡɝz, hi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə wʊmən ət ðə dɔɹ, ɪn ðə pleɪn dɑɹk dʒɹɛs ʌv ə meɪd. nɑt ðət ðəɾ izd ɪz maɪn baɪ ə hɛɹ.

Finding the correct street, much less the correct house, was not one narrow side street looked very like another when darkness swathed both - but he took a care and eventually found himself pounding on the front doors of a tall, shadowed pile that could have belonged to a wealthy but discreet merchant. Except he knew now that it did not. Avarhin was a tiny House, extinct some said, but one daughter of it remained, and Shiaine possessed money. One of the doors swung open, and he flung up a hand against the sudden glare of light. His left hand; the dagger in his right, he kept concealed and ready. Squinting through his spread fingers, he recognized the woman at the door, in the plain dark dress of a maid. Not that that eased his mind by a hair.

"ɡɪv əs ə kɪs, fæljən," hi sɛɾ əz i stɛpt ɪnsaɪd. lɪɹɪŋ, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ hɝ. lɛft-hændəd, ʌv kɔɹs.

"Give us a kiss, Falion," he said as he stepped inside. Leering, he reached for her. Left-handed, of course.

ðə lɔŋ-feɪst wʊmən bɹʌʃt ɪz hæn əsaɪɾ ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ fɝmli bɪhaɪn hɪm. "ʃieɪn ɪz klɑzəɾɪd wɪð ə vɪzəɾɝ ɪn ðə fɹʌn sɪɾɪŋ ɹum əpstɛɹz," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, "æn ðə kʊk ɪz ɪn əɹ bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn ðə haʊs. hæŋ jəɹ kloʊk ɑn ðə ɹæk. əl lɛɾ əɹ noʊ jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, bʌt jə meɪ hæv tə weɪt."

The long-faced woman brushed his hand aside and shut the door firmly behind him. "Shiaine is closeted with a visitor in the front sitting room upstairs," she said calmly, "and the cook is in her bedchamber. There is no one else in the house. Hang your cloak on the rack. I will let her know you are here, but you may have to wait."

hænlən lɛɾ ɪz lɪɹ vænɪʃ ən ɪz hæn dʒɹɑp. fəɹ ɔl ə hɝ eɪdʒləs feɪs, hænsəm wɑz ðə bɛs ðət fæljən kəd bi kɔld, ən ivən ðət maɪt bi stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ, wɪð əɹ koʊld ɡeɪz ən ə koʊldɝ mænɝ ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən. ʃi wɑz hɑɹdli ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊmən i wʊɾə tʃoʊzən tə fɑndəl, bʌɾ ɪt simd ʃi wɑz biɪŋ pʌnɪʃt baɪ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən ən i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə pʌnɪʃmənt, wɪtʃ ɔltɝd mæɾɝz. tə səm ɪkstɛnt. tʌmbəlɪŋ ə wʊmən u hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs hæd nɛvɝ tʃɹʌbəl hɪm, ən fæljən sɝɾənli hæd nʌn. hɝ meɪdz dʒɹɛs wɑz sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ; ʃi dɪd ðə wɝk ə fɔɹ əɹ faɪv wɪmən baɪ hɝsɛlf, meɪdz ən skʌljənz ən spɪt-ɡɝl, slipɪŋ wən ʃi kəɾ ən tʃɹʌklɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ ʃieɪn fɹaʊnd. hɝ hænz wɝ ɹʌf ən ɹɛd fɹəm duɪŋ lɔnʒɹi ən skɹʌbɪŋ flɔɹz. jɛt ʃi wɑz laɪkli tə sɝvaɪv əɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, ən ðə læs θɪŋ i wɑntəd wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ə pɝsənəl ɡɹʌdʒ əɡɛns dɑv hænlən. nɑt wən sɝkəmstænsəz maɪt wɛl tʃeɪnʒ bɪfɔɹ i hæɾ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə pʊɾ ə naɪf θɹu hɝ hɑɹt, ɛniweɪ.

Hanlon let his leer vanish and his hand drop. For all of her ageless face, handsome was the best that Falion could be called, and even that might be stretching the truth, with her cold gaze and a colder manner in the bargain. She was hardly the sort of woman he would have chosen to fondle, but it seemed she was being punished by one of the Chosen and he was supposed to be part of the punishment, which altered matters. To some extent. Tumbling a woman who had no choice had never troubled him, and Falion certainly had none. Her maid's dress was simple truth; she did the work of four or five women by herself, maids and scullions and spit-girl, sleeping when she could and truckling whenever Shiaine frowned. Her hands were rough and red from doing laundry and scrubbing floors. Yet she was likely to survive her punishment, and the last thing he wanted was an Aes Sedai with a personal grudge against Daved Hanlon. Not when circumstances might well change before he had an opportunity to put a knife through her heart, anyway.

ɹitʃɪŋ ən əkɑmədeɪʃən wɪð əɹ hæd bɪn izi, ðoʊ. ʃi sim tə hæv ə pɹæktəkəl vju. wən ʌðɝz kəd si, hi ɹʌmpəld əɹ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi keɪm ɪn ɹitʃ, ən wən ðəɹ wɑz taɪm, hi bʌndəld əɹ ʌp tə hɝ taɪni meɪdz ɹum ʌndɝ ði ivz. wɛɹ ðeɪ mʌs ðə bɛdkloʊðz, ðən sæɾ ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛɾ ɪn ðə koʊld ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ðoʊ əɾ əɹ ɝdʒɪŋ, hi dɪd ɡɪv əɹ ə fju bɹuzəz, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ʃieɪn tʃoʊz tə tʃɛk. hi hoʊpt ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz əɾ əɹ ɝdʒɪŋ.

Reaching an accommodation with her had been easy, though. She seemed to have a practical view. When others could see, he rumpled her every time she came in reach, and when there was time, he bundled her up to her tiny maid's room under the eaves. Where they mussed the bedclothes, then sat on the narrow bed in the cold and exchanged information. Though at her urging, he did give her a few bruises, just in case Shiaine chose to check. He hoped she remembered that it was at her urging.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ ði ʌðɝz?" hi sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɔf ən hæŋɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə lɛpɝd-kɑɹv kloʊk ɹæk. ðə saʊn ə hɪz buts ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz baʊns fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹi hɔlz haɪ silɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə faɪn speɪs, wɪð peɪntəd plæstɝ kɔɹnɪsəz ən sɛvɹəl ɹɪtʃ wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz ɑn kɑɹv pænəlz ðət wɝ pɑlɪʃt tə ə feɪnt ɡloʊ, wɛl lɪt baɪ mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps wɪð ɪnʌf ɡɪldɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪtsɛlf, bʌt bɝn ɪm ɪf ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ wɔɹmɝ ðən aʊtsaɪd. fæljən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ɪz hænd, ən i ʃiðd ɪt wɪð ə taɪt smaɪl. hi kəɾ əv ɪɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn fæstɝ ðən ɛniwʌn wəd bɪliv, ən ɪz sɔɹd nɪɹ əz fæst. "ðə stʃɹits ɑɹ fʊl ə θivz ət naɪt." dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɪl, hi ɹimuvd ɪz ɡɔnləts ən tʌkt əm bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls maɪt meɪk ɪɾ əpɪɹ i θɔt hɪmsɛlf ɪn deɪnʒɝ. ðə bɹɛstpleɪt ʃəd bi ɪnʌf ɛniweɪ, kʌm ðə wɝst.

"Where are the others?" he said, swinging his cloak off and hanging it on the leopard-carved cloak rack. The sound of his boots on the floor tiles bounced from the entry hall's high ceiling. It was a fine space, with painted plaster cornices and several rich wall hangings on carved panels that were polished to a faint glow, well lit by mirrored stand-lamps with enough gilding for the Royal Palace itself, but burn him if it was much warmer than outside. Falion raised an eyebrow at the dagger in his hand, and he sheathed it with a tight smile. He could have it out again faster than anyone would believe, and his sword near as fast. "The streets are full of thieves at night." Despite the chill, he removed his gauntlets and tucked them behind his sword belt. Anything else might make it appear he thought himself in danger. The breastplate should be enough anyway, come the worst.

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛɹ mɑɹilɪn ɪz," ʃi sɛɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ɔlɹɛɾi tɝnɪŋ əweɪ ən ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ skɝts fəɹ ðə stɛɹstɛps. "ʃi wɛn aʊt bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt. mɹɛlɪn ɪz ɪn ðə steɪbəlz wɪð ɪz paɪp. wi kən tɔk æftɝ aɪ ɪnfɔɹm ʃieɪn juv ɝaɪvd."

"I do not know where Marillin is," she said over her shoulder, already turning away and gathering her skirts for the stairsteps. "She went out before sunset. Murellin is in the stables with his pipe. We can talk after I inform Shiaine you've arrived."

wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ klaɪm ðə stɛɹz, hi ɡɹʌntɪd. mɹɛlɪn, ə hʌlkɪŋ fɛloʊ hænlən dɪd nɑt laɪk əɾ ɪz bæk, wɑz bænɪʃt tə ðə steɪbəlz bɪhaɪn ðə haʊs wɛnɛvɝ i wɑntəd tə smoʊk ɪz paɪp, kəz ʃieɪn dɪslaɪk ðə smɛl ə ðə ɹʌf təbæk i juzd, ən sɪns i juʒəwəli tʊk ə pɑɾ ʌv eɪl wɪð hɪm, əɹ ivən ə pɪtʃɝ, hi ʃəd nɑt bi kʌmɪŋ ɪn ɛni taɪm sun. mɑɹilɪn wɝiɾ ɪm mɔɹ. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu, əpɛɹənli əz mʌtʃ ʌndɝ ʃieɪnz ɔɹɾɝz əz fæljən, əɹ hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ əɡɹiməns wɪð hɝ. noʊ ɑɹɡjəməns, iðɝ, jɛɾ i dɪstʃɹʌstəɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn pɹɪnsəpəl, blæk ədʒɑ əɹ nɑt. wɛɹ hæd ʃi ɡɔn? tə də wʌt? wʌɾ ə mæn dɪd nɑt noʊ kəd kɪl hɪm, ən mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn spɛn ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ taɪm ɔf duɪŋ θɪŋz i nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt. hi wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə ðə kənkluʒən ðət ðəɹ wɝ ɪntaɪɝli tu mɛni θɪŋz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn i nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt. pæs taɪm i lɝnd, ɪf i wɑntəd tə lɪv.

Watching her climb the stairs, he grunted. Murellin, a hulking fellow Hanlon did not like at his back, was banished to the stables behind the house whenever he wanted to smoke his pipe, because Shiaine disliked the smell of the rough tabac he used, and since he usually took a pot of ale with him, or even a pitcher, he should not be coming in any time soon. Marillin worried him more. She was Aes Sedai, too, apparently as much under Shiaine's orders as Falion, or himself, but he had no agreements with her. No arguments, either, yet he distrusted any Aes Sedai on principle, Black Ajah or not. Where had she gone? To do what? What a man did not know could kill him, and Marillin Gemalphin spent entirely too much time off doing things he knew nothing about. He was coming to the conclusion that there were entirely too many things in Caemlyn he knew nothing about. Past time he learned, if he wanted to live.

wɪð fæljən ɡɔn, hi wɛn fɹəm ði aɪsi ɛntʃɹi hɔl stʃɹeɪt tə ðə kɪtʃən ət ðə bæk ə ðə haʊs.

With Falion gone, he went from the icy entry hall straight to the kitchen at the back of the house.

ðə bɹɪk-wɔld ɹum wɑz ɛmpti, ʌv kɔɹs - ðə kʊk nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə poʊk əɹ noʊz aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹum ɪn ðə beɪsmənt wʌns ʃi wɑz sɛn əweɪ fəɹ ðə naɪt - ən ðə blæk aɪɝn stoʊv ən ði ʌvənz stʊd koʊld, bʌɾ ə smɔl bleɪz ɑn ðə lɔŋ stoʊn hɑɹθ meɪd ðə kɪtʃən wʌn ə ðə fju ɹumz ɪn ðə haʊs ðət wəd bi wɔɹm. kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ɹɛst, ət list. ʃieɪn wɑz ə stɪnʒi wʊmən, ɪksɛpt wən ɪt keɪm tə hɝ oʊn kʌmfɝts. ðə faɪɝ hɪɹ wɑz oʊnli ɪn keɪs ʃi hæpən tə wɑn mʌld waɪn ɪn ðə naɪt, əɹ ə hiɾəd ɛɡ-mɪlk. hi hæd bɪn ɪn ðɪs haʊs əbʌv hæf ə dʌzən taɪmz sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən i nu wɪtʃ kæbənəts hɛl ðə spaɪsəz ən wɪtʃ ɹum ɔf ðə kɪtʃən ɔlweɪz hɛld ə kæsk ʌv waɪn. ɔlweɪz ɡʊd waɪn. ʃieɪn nɛvɝ stɪntɪd ðɛɹ. nɑt wɪð ðət ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə dʒɹɪŋk hɝsɛlf, ɛniweɪ. baɪ ðə taɪm fæljən ɹɪtɝnd, hi hæd ðə hʌnipɑɾ ən ə dɪʃ ə dʒɪnʒɝ ən kloʊvz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə waɪd kɪtʃən teɪbəl wɪð ə pɪtʃɝ fʊl ʌv waɪn, ən ə poʊkɝ θɹʌst ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. ʃieɪn maɪt seɪ "kʌm naʊ" ən min "naʊ," bʌt wən ʃi wɑntəd tə meɪk ə mæn weɪt, ɪt kəd bi nɪɹ deɪlaɪt bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɔ hɪm. ðiz kɔlz ɔlweɪz kɑst ɪm slip, bɝn ðə wʊmən! "hu ɪz ðə vɪzəɾɝ?" hi æskt.

The brick-walled room was empty, of course - the cook knew better than to poke her nose out of her room in the basement once she was sent away for the night - and the black iron stove and the ovens stood cold, but a small blaze on the long stone hearth made the kitchen one of the few rooms in the house that would be warm. Compared to the rest, at least. Shiaine was a stingy woman, except when it came to her own comforts. The fire here was only in case she happened to want mulled wine in the night, or a heated egg-milk. He had been in this house above half a dozen times since coming to Caemlyn, and he knew which cabinets held the spices and which room off the kitchen always held a cask of wine. Always good wine. Shiaine never stinted there. Not with that she intended to drink herself, anyway. By the time Falion returned, he had the honeypot and a dish of ginger and cloves sitting on the wide kitchen table with a pitcher full of wine, and a poker thrust into the fire. Shiaine might say "come now" and mean "now," but when she wanted to make a man wait, it could be near daylight before she saw him. These calls always cost him sleep, burn the woman! "Who is the visitor?" he asked.

"hi ɡeɪv noʊ neɪm, nɑt tə mi," fæljən sɛd, pɹɑpɪŋ ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl oʊpən wɪð ə tʃɛɹ. ðət lɛt səm ə ðə spɑɹs wɔɹmθ lik aʊt, bʌt ʃi wəd wɑnə bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ ɪf ʃieɪn sʌmən hɝ.

"He gave no name, not to me," Falion said, propping the door to the hall open with a chair. That let some of the sparse warmth leak out, but she would want to be able to hear if Shiaine summoned her.

əɹ meɪbi ʃi wɑntəd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz nɑɾ eɪbəl tə ivzdʒɹɑp. "ə lin mæn, tɔl ən hɑɹd, wɪð ðə lʊk ʌv ə soʊlʒɝ. ən ɔfəsɝ ə səm ɹæŋk, meɪbi ə noʊbəl, baɪ hɪz mænɝ, ən ændɔɝən baɪ hɪz æksɛns. hi simz ɪntɛlədʒən ən kɔʃəs. hɪz kloʊðz ɑɹ kwaɪt pleɪn, ðoʊ kɑsli, ən i wɛɹz noʊ ɹɪŋz əɹ pɪnz." fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə teɪbəl, ʃi tɝn tə wʌn ə ðə tɔl oʊpən-fɹʌn kæbənəts bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔlweɪ ən æɾəd ə sɛkən pjuɾɝ kʌp tə ðə wʌn i hæd sɛɾ aʊt fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. ɪt hæd nɛvɝ əkɝd tə hɪm tə sɛɾ aʊt tu. bæɾ ɪnʌf i hæd tə fɪks ɪz oʊn waɪn. ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wɑz ðə meɪd. bʌt ʃi tʊk ə tʃɛɹ ət ðə teɪbəl ən pʊʃt ðə dɪʃ ə spaɪsəz əweɪ fɹəm əɹ fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ðoʊ ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə sɝv.

Or maybe she wanted to make sure the other woman was not able to eavesdrop. "A lean man, tall and hard, with the look of a soldier. An officer of some rank, maybe a noble, by his manner, and Andoran by his accents. He seems intelligent and cautious. His clothes are quite plain, though costly, and he wears no rings or pins." Frowning at the table, she turned to one of the tall open-front cabinets beside the door to the hallway and added a second pewter cup to the one he had set out for himself. It had never occurred to him to set out two. Bad enough he had to fix his own wine. Aes Sedai or no Aes Sedai, she was the maid. But she took a chair at the table and pushed the dish of spices away from her for all the world as though she expected him to serve.

"ʃieɪn hæd tu vɪzəɾɝz jɛstɝdeɪ, haʊɛvɝ, mɔɹ kɛɹləs ðən ðɪs fɛloʊ," ʃi wɛn ɑn.

"Shiaine had two visitors yesterday, however, more careless than this fellow," she went on.

"wʌn, ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, hæd ðə ɡoʊldən bɔɹz ə sɑɝən ɑn ðə kʌf ə hɪz ɡɔnləts. hi pɹɑbli θɔt noʊ wʌn wəd noʊɾəs smɔl-wɝk, ɪf i θɔɾ əɾ ɔl. ə plʌmp, jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz u lʊk daʊn ɪz noʊz əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, kəmpləmɛntɪd ðə waɪn əz ðoʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ə disən vɪntɪdʒ ɪn ðə haʊs, ən wɑntəd ʃieɪn tə hæv mi biɾən fəɹ ʃoʊɪŋ ɪnsəfɪʃən ɹɪspɛkt." ʃi sɛɾ ivən ðəɾ ɪn ə koʊld, mɛʒɝd vɔɪs. ði oʊnli taɪm ʃi hæd hæɾ ɛni hiɾ ɪn əɹ wɑz wən ʃieɪn pʊt ðə stʃɹæp tə hɝ. hi hæd hɝɾ əɹ haʊl ɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf ðɛn. "ə kʌntʃɹimən u hæz sɛldəm bɪn tə keɪɛmlɪn bʌt bɪlivz i noʊz haʊ hɪz bɛɾɝz bɪheɪv, aɪ ʃəd seɪ. jə kən mɑɹk ɪm baɪ ə wɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɪn ən ə smɔl hæf-mun skɑɹ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz lɛft aɪ. ðə fɛloʊ ɪn ði æftɝnun wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ən dɑɹk, wɪð ə ʃɑɹp noʊz ən wɛɹi aɪz, ən noʊ skɑɹz əɹ mɑɹks aɪ kəd si, ðoʊ hi wɔɹ ə ɹɪŋ wɪð ə skwɛɹ ɡɑɹnəɾ ɑn ɪz lɛf hænd. hi wɑz spɛɹɪŋ wɪð wɝdz, vɛɹi maɪnfəl tə ɡɪv əweɪ nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə lɪɾəl aɪ hɝd, bʌɾ i kæɹiɾ ə dæɡɝ wɪð ðə fɔɹ munz ə haʊs mɑɹn ɑn ðə pɑməl." foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz, hænlən lin əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝ pleɪs ən kɛpt ɪz feɪs smuð dɪspaɪɾ ə dɪzaɪɝ tə skaʊl. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ðət ðə plæn wɑz fəɹ ɪleɪn tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn, ðoʊ wʌt keɪm æftɝ ɹɪmeɪn ə mɪstɝi. ʃi hæd bɪn pɹɑməs tə hɪm əz ə kwin. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi wɔɹ ə kɹaʊn wən i tʊk əɹ mæɾɝd nɑɾ ə wɪt tə hɪm ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə spaɪs ɪɾ æɾəd - bɹeɪkɪŋ ðət lɔŋ-lɛɡəd bɪt tə sæɾəl wəd bi pjʊɹ plɛʒɝ ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ə fɑɹmɝz dɔɾɝ, ɪspɛʃli æftɝ ðə tʃɪt kʌɾ ə slaɪs ɔf ɪm tədeɪ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɔl ðoʊz ʌðɝ wɪmən! - bʌt dilɪŋz wɪð sɑɝən ən mɑɹn sɛd meɪbi ɪleɪn wɑz mɛn tə daɪ ʌnkɹoʊnd. meɪbi, ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv ɔl ðə pɹɑməsəz ðəɾ i kəd ɹɑmp ə kwin, hi hæd bɪn pleɪst wɛɹ i wɑz soʊ hi kəd kɪl əɹ ət səm səlɛktəd moʊmənt, wən əɹ dɛθ wəd bɹɪŋ səm spəsɪfɪk ɹɪzʌl sɔt baɪ ʃieɪn. əɹ ɹæðɝ baɪ ðə tʃoʊzən u hæd ɡɪvən əɹ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz. mɔɹaɪɾɪn, ðə fɛloʊ wɑz kɔld, ə neɪm hænlən hæd nɛvɝ hɝd bɪfɔɹ kɑm ɪŋ tə ðɪs haʊs.

"One, in the morning, had the Golden Boars of Sarand on the cuff of his gauntlets. He probably thought no one would notice small-work, if he thought at all. A plump, yellow-haired man in his middle years who looked down his nose at everything, complimented the wine as though surprised to find a decent vintage in the house, and wanted Shiaine to have me beaten for showing insufficient respect." She said even that in a cold, measured voice. The only time she had had any heat in her was when Shiaine put the strap to her. He had heard her howl right enough then. "A countryman who has seldom been to Caemlyn but believes he knows how his betters behave, I should say. You can mark him by a wart on his chin and a small half-moon scar beside his left eye. The fellow in the afternoon was short and dark, with a sharp nose and wary eyes, and no scars or marks I could see, though he wore a ring with a square garnet on his left hand. He was sparing with words, very mindful to give away nothing in the little I heard, but he carried a dagger with the Four Moons of House Marne on the pommel." Folding his arms, Hanlon leaned against the side of the fire place and kept his face smooth despite a desire to scowl. He had been sure that the plan was for Elayne to take the throne, though what came after remained a mystery. She had been promised to him as a queen. Whether or not she wore a crown when he took her mattered not a whit to him except for the spice it added - breaking that long-legged bit to saddle would be pure pleasure if she had been a farmer's daughter, especially after the chit cut a slice off him today in front of all those other women! - but dealings with Sarand and Marne said maybe Elayne was meant to die uncrowned. Maybe, in spite of all the promises that he could romp a queen, he had been placed where he was so he could kill her at some selected moment, when her death would bring some specific result sought by Shiaine. Or rather by the Chosen who had given her her orders. Moridin, the fellow was called, a name Hanlon had never heard before com ing to this house.

ðət dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌbəl hɪm. ɪf ə mæn hæd ðə nɝv tə kɔl hɪmsɛlf wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, hænlən wɑz nɑt ful ɪnʌf tə kwɛstʃən ɪt. ðə laɪklihʊd ðəɾ i wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə dæɡɝ ɪn ðɪs dɪd tʃɹʌbəl hɪm. soʊ lɔŋ əz ə dæɡɝ dɪd ðə dʒɑb, wʌt mæɾɝ ɪf ɪt bɹoʊk ɪn ðə duɪŋ? mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tə bi ðə fɪst ɑn ðə hɪl ðən ðə bleɪd.

That did not trouble him. If a man had the nerve to call himself one of the Chosen, Hanlon was not fool enough to question it. The likelihood that he was no more than a dagger in this did trouble him. So long as a dagger did the job, what matter if it broke in the doing? Much better to be the fist on the hilt than the blade.

"dɪd jə si ɛni ɡoʊl tʃeɪnʒ hænz?" hi æskt. "dɪd jə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ?"

"Did you see any gold change hands?" he asked. "Did you hear anything?"

"aɪ wəɾ əv sɛd," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd θɪnli. "æn baɪ əɹ əɡɹimənt, ɪts maɪ tɝn fəɹ ə kwɛstʃən." hi mænədʒ tə mæsk ɪz ɪɹɪteɪʃən bɪhaɪn ən ɪkspɛktən lʊk. ðə ful wʊmən ɔlweɪz æskt əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə pæləs əɹ ðoʊz ʃi kɔl ðə kɪn, əɹ əbaʊt ðə si foʊk. sɪli kwɛstʃənz. hu wɑz fɹɛnli wɪð hum, ən u ənfɹɛnli. hu ɪkstʃeɪnʒd pɹaɪvət wɝdz ən u əvɔɪɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ.

"I would have said," she replied thinly. "And by our agreement, it is my turn for a question." He managed to mask his irritation behind an expectant look. The fool woman always asked about the Aes Sedai in the palace or those she called the Kin, or about the Sea Folk. Silly questions. Who was friendly with whom, and who unfriendly. Who exchanged private words and who avoided one another.

wʌɾ i hæd hɝɾ əm seɪ. əz ɪf i hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪz taɪm bʌt lɝk ɝaʊn ðə hɔlweɪz spaɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛm. hi nɛvɝ laɪd tə hɝ - ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ tʃæns ʃi maɪt lɝn ðə tʃɹuθ, ivən maɪɹd hɪɹ ɪn ðɪs haʊs əz ə meɪd; ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, æftɝ ɔl - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɪfəkəl tə kʌm ʌp wɪð sʌmθɪŋ i hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl hɝ, ən ʃi wɑz æɾəmənt ðəɾ i ɡɪv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪf i ɪkspɛktəd tə ɹəsiv ɛni. stɪl, hi hæɾ ə fju tɪdbɪts tə ɔfɝ tədeɪ, səm ə ðə si foʊk ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf, ən ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm dʒʌmpɪŋ fəɹ moʊst ə ðə deɪ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ aɪsɪkəlz ʃʌv daʊn ðɛɹ bæks. ʃi wəɾ əv tə sɛɾəl fəɹ ðæt. wʌɾ i niɾəd tə noʊ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, nɑt blʌɾi ɡɑsəp.

What he had heard them say. As if he had nothing to do with his time but lurk around the hallways spying on them. He never lied to her - there was too much chance she might learn the truth, even mired here in this house as a maid; she was Aes Sedai, after all - but it was growing difficult to come up with something he had not already told her, and she was adamant that he give information if he expected to receive any. Still, he had a few tidbits to offer today, some of the Sea Folk going off, and the whole lot of them jumping for most of the day as if they had icicles shoved down their backs. She would have to settle for that. What he needed to know was important, not bloody gossip.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ kwɛstʃən aʊt, ðoʊ, ðə dɔɹ tə ði aʊtsaɪɾ oʊpənd. mɹɛlɪn wɑz lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i ɔlmoʊs fɪl ðə dɔɹweɪ, jɛɾ aɪsi koʊl stɪl swɝld ɪn, ə ɡʌs ðət meɪd ðə smɔl faɪɝ dæns ən sɛn spɑɹks flaɪɪŋ ʌp ðə tʃɪmni əntɪl ðə bɪɡ mæn pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt. hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðəɾ i fɛl ðə tʃɪl, bʌt ðɛn, hɪz bɹaʊn koʊt lʊk θɪk əz tu kloʊks. bɪsaɪdz, ðə mæn wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli ðə saɪz ʌv ən ɑks, hi hæd ðə wɪts ʌv wʌn. sɛɾɪŋ ə tɔl wʊɾən mʌɡ daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə θʌmp, hi tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz waɪd bɛlt ən aɪd hænlən ɹɪzɛnfəli. "ju mɛsɪŋ wɪð maɪ wʊmən?" hi mʌɾɝd.

Before she could get her question out, though, the door to the outside opened. Murellin was large enough that he almost filled the doorway, yet icy cold still swirled in, a gust that made the small fire dance and sent sparks flying up the chimney until the big man pushed the door shut. He gave no sign that he felt the chill, but then, his brown coat looked thick as two cloaks. Besides, the man was not only the size of an ox, he had the wits of one. Setting a tall wooden mug down on the table with a thump, he tucked his thumbs behind his wide belt and eyed Hanlon resentfully. "You messing with my woman?" he muttered.

hænlən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. nɑt fɹəm ɛni fɪɹ ə mɹɛlɪn, nɑt wɪð ði ɑf ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl.

Hanlon gave a start. Not from any fear of Murellin, not with the oaf on the other side of the table.

wʌt stɑɹɾəld ɪm wɑz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lipɪŋ fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ ən snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə waɪn pɪtʃɝ. dʌmpɪŋ ɪn ðə dʒɪnʒɝ ən kloʊvz, ʃi æɾəd ə skup ə hʌni ən swɝl ðə pɪtʃɝ ɝaʊn əz ɪf ðət wɑz gɑnə mɪks ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ðən juzd ə foʊld ə hɝ skɝt tə pʊl ðə poʊkɝ fɹəm ðə faɪɝ ən ʃʌv ɪɾ ɪndə ðə waɪn wɪθaʊt tʃɛkɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz hɑɾ ɪnʌf jɛt. ʃi nɛvɝ lʊkt ɪn mɹɛlɪnz dɝɛkʃən əɾ ɔl.

What startled him was the Aes Sedai leaping from her chair and snatching up the wine pitcher. Dumping in the ginger and cloves, she added a scoop of honey and swirled the pitcher around as if that was going to mix everything, then used a fold of her skirt to pull the poker from the fire and shove it into the wine without checking to see whether it was hot enough yet. She never looked in Murellin's direction at all.

"jɔɹ wʊmən?" hænlən sɛd kɛɹfəli. ðəɾ ɝn ə smɝk fɹəm ði ʌðɝ mæn.

"Your woman?" Hanlon said carefully. That earned a smirk from the other man.

"nɪɹ ɪnʌf. ðə leɪɾi fɪɡjɝɾ aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl jus wʌt jə ɑɹənt. ɛniweɪ, fæli ən mi kip itʃ ʌðɝ wɔɹm naɪts." mɹɛlɪn stɑɹɾəd ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl, stɪl ɡɹɪnɪŋ, bʌɾ ət ðə wʊmən, naʊ.

"Near enough. The Lady figured I might as well use what you aren't. Anyway, Fally and me keep each other warm nights." Murellin started around the table, still grinning, but at the woman, now.

ə ʃaʊɾ ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, ən i stɑpt wɪð ə saɪ, hɪz ɡɹɪn feɪɾɪŋ.

A shout echoed in the hallway, and he stopped with a sigh, his grin fading.

"fæljən!" ʃieɪnz dɪstən vɔɪs kɔld ʃɑɹpli. "bɹɪŋ hænlən ʌp naʊ ən bi kwɪk əbaʊɾ ɪt!" fæljən sɛt ðə pɪtʃɝ ɑn ðə teɪbəl hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə slɑp waɪn oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ən wɑz hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃieɪn fɪnɪʃt. wən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən spoʊk, fæljən dʒʌmpt.

"Falion!" Shiaine's distant voice called sharply. "Bring Hanlon up now and be quick about it!" Falion set the pitcher on the table hard enough to slop wine over the rim and was heading for the door before Shiaine finished. When the other woman spoke, Falion jumped.

hænlən dʒʌmp tu, ɪf fəɹ ə dɪfɹən ɹizən. kætʃɪŋ ʌp tə hɝ, hi sizd əɹ ɑɹm əz ʃi tʊk ðə fɝst stɛp ɑn ðə stɛɹz. ə kwɪk ɡlæns bæk ʃoʊd ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹ kloʊzd. meɪbi mɹɛlɪn dɪd fil ðə koʊld. hi kɛpt ɪz vɔɪs loʊ ɛniweɪ. "wʌt wɑz ðəɾ ɔl əbaʊt?"

Hanlon jumped too, if for a different reason. Catching up to her, he seized her arm as she took the first step on the stairs. A quick glance back showed the kitchen door closed. Maybe Murellin did feel the cold. He kept his voice low anyway. "What was that all about?"

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌn ə jəɹ bɪznəs," ʃi sɛd kɝtli. "kæn jə ɡɛt mi sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɪl meɪk ɪm slip? sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kən pʊɾ ɪn ɪz eɪl əɹ waɪn? hɪl dʒɹɪŋk ɛniθɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ ɪt teɪsts." "ɪf ʃieɪn θɪŋks aɪm nɑɾ oʊbeɪɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz, ɪt blʌɾi wɛl ɪz maɪ bɪznəs, ən jə ɔt tə si ɪt ðət weɪ, tu, ɪf juv tu blʌɾi θɔts tə ɹʌb təɡɛðɝ."

"It is none of your business," she said curtly. "Can you get me something that will make him sleep? Something I can put in his ale or wine? He will drink anything, however it tastes." "If Shiaine thinks I'm not obeying orders, it bloody well is my business, and you ought to see it that way, too, if you have two bloody thoughts to rub together."

ʃi tɪltəɾ əɹ hɛd, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðət lɔŋ noʊz ət hɪm, koʊld əz ə fɪʃ. "ðɪs əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ju. əz fɑɹ əz ʃieɪn ɪz kənsɝnd, əl stɪl bɪlɔŋ tə jə wən jə ɑɹ hɪɹ. jə si, sɝɾən mæɾɝz tʃeɪnʒd." sʌɾənli, sʌmθɪŋ ənsin ɡɹæspt ɪz ɹɪs taɪtli ən pʊld ɪz hæn fɹəm əɹ sliv. sʌmθɪŋ ɛls lætʃt ɑn tə hɪz θɹoʊt, skwizɪŋ tɪl i kəd nɑt dʒɹɔ bɹɛθ.

She tilted her head, staring down that long nose at him, cold as a fish. "This has nothing to do with you. As far as Shiaine is concerned, I will still belong to you when you are here. You see, certain matters changed." Suddenly, something unseen grasped his wrist tightly and pulled his hand from her sleeve. Something else latched on to his throat, squeezing till he could not draw breath.

fjuɾɪlli, hi skɹæbəld lɛft-hændəd fəɹ ɪz dæɡɝ. hɝ toʊn ɹɪmeɪn kul. "aɪ θɔt sɝɾən ʌðɝ mæɾɝz ʃəd tʃeɪnʒ əkɔɹɾɪŋli, bʌt ʃieɪn dʌz nɑt si θɪŋz lɑdʒɪkli. ʃi sɛz ðət wən ðə ɡɹeɪt mæstɝ mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɪʃɪz maɪ pʌnɪʃmən lɛsənd, hɪl seɪ soʊ. mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɡeɪv mi tə hɝ.

Futilely, he scrabbled left-handed for his dagger. Her tone remained cool. "I thought certain other matters should change accordingly, but Shiaine does not see things logically. She says that when the Great Master Moridin wishes my punishment lessened, he will say so. Moridin gave me to her.

mɹɛlɪn ɪz əɹ weɪ ʌv meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. hɝ weɪ ʌv meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ aɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪm əɹ dɔɡ əntɪl ʃi sɛz ʌðɝwaɪz." əbɹʌpli ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ðə pɹɛʃɝ vænɪʃt fɹəm ɪz ɹɪst ən θɹoʊt. ɛɹ hæd nɛvɝ teɪstəd soʊ swit. "ju kən ɡɛt wʌɾ aɪ æsk fɔɹ?" ʃi sɛd, əz kɑm əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt dʒʌs tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm wɪð ðə blʌɾi paʊɝ. dʒʌs ðə θɔt ðət ðət hæd bɪn tʌtʃɪŋ ɪm meɪɾ ɪz skɪn kɹɔl.

Murellin is her way of making sure I understand that. Her way of making sure I know that I am her dog until she says otherwise." Abruptly she drew a deep breath, and the pressure vanished from his wrist and throat. Air had never tasted so sweet. "You can get what I ask for?" she said, as calm as if she had not just tried to kill him with the bloody Power. Just the thought that that had been touching him made his skin crawl.

"aɪ kən . . . " hi bɪɡæn hɔɹsli, ən stɑp tə swɑloʊ, ɹʌbɪŋ əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. ɪt fɛlt əz ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn sɪntʃt ɪn ə hæŋmənz nus. "aɪ kən ɡɛt jə sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɪl pʊɾ ɪm ɪn ə slip hɪl nɛvɝ weɪk fɹʌm." əz sun əz ɪt wɑz seɪf, hi wɑz gɑnə ɡʌɾ əɹ laɪk ə ɡus.

"I can . . . " he began hoarsely, and stopped to swallow, rubbing at his throat. It felt as though it had been cinched in a hangman's noose. "I can get you something that will put him in a sleep he'll never wake from." As soon as it was safe, he was going to gut her like a goose.

ʃi snɔɹɾɪd dɝɪsɪvli. "aɪ wəd bi ðə fɝst ʃieɪn səspɛktəd, ən aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl kʌt maɪ oʊn ɹɪsts əz əbdʒɛk tə ɛniθɪŋ ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə du. ɪɾəl bi ɪnʌf ɪf i slips ðə naɪts θɹu. liv ðə θɪŋkɪŋ tə mi, ən wɪl boʊθ bi ðə bɛɾɝ fəɹ ɪt."

She snorted derisively. "I would be the first Shiaine suspected, and I might as well cut my own wrists as object to anything she decided to do. It will be enough if he sleeps the nights through. Leave the thinking to me, and we will both be the better for it."

ɹɛstɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ðə kɑɹv nuəlpoʊst, ʃi ɡlænst ʌp ðə stɛɹz. "kʌm. wən ʃi sɛz naʊ, ʃi minz naʊ." ə pɪɾi hi kəd nɑt hæŋ əɹ ʌp laɪk ə ɡus tə weɪt fəɹ ðə naɪf. fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ, hɪz buts θʌmpt ɑn ðə tʃɹɛdz, sɛndɪŋ ə klæɾɝ θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi hɔl, ən ɪt stʃɹʌk ɪm ðəɾ i hæd nɑt hɝd ðə vɪzəɾɝ liv. ənlɛs ðə haʊs hæd səm sikɹət weɪ aʊɾ i dɪd nɑt noʊ, ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ, ðə wʌn ɪn ðə kɪtʃən, ən ə sɛkən ət ðə bæk ðət kəɾ oʊnli bi ɹitʃt baɪ pæsɪŋ ðə kɪtʃən. soʊ ɪt simd i wɑz tə mit ðɪs soʊlʒɝ. meɪbi ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə kʌm əz ə sɝpɹaɪz.

Resting a hand on the carved newelpost, she glanced up the stairs. "Come. When she says now, she means now." A pity he could not hang her up like a goose to wait for the knife. Following her, his boots thumped on the treads, sending a clatter through the entry hall, and it struck him that he had not heard the visitor leave. Unless the house had some secret way out he did not know, there was only the front door, the one in the kitchen, and a second at the back that could only be reached by passing the kitchen. So it seemed he was to meet this soldier. Maybe it was supposed to come as a surprise.

sɝəptɪʃəsli, hi izd ɪz dæɡɝ ɪn ɪts ʃiθ.

Surreptitiously, he eased his dagger in its sheath.

əz ɪkspɛktəd, ðə fɹʌn sɪɾɪŋ ɹum hæɾ ə faɪn bleɪz bɝnɪŋ əweɪ ɪn ðə waɪd faɪɝpleɪs ə blu-veɪn mɑɹbəl. ɪt wɑz ə ɹum wɝθ ðə luɾɪŋ, wɪð si foʊk pɔɹsələn veɪsəz ɑn ðə ɡɪlt-ɛdʒ saɪd teɪbəlz, ən tæpəstʃɹiz ən kɑɹpəts ðət wəd fɛtʃ ə pɹɪɾi pɹaɪs. ɪksɛp ðət wʌn ə ðə kɑɹpəts wɑz laɪkli wɝθləs, naʊ. ə loʊ blæŋkət-kʌvɝd maʊn leɪ nɪɹ ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum, ən ɪf ðə fɛloʊ ðət meɪɾ ɪt hæd nɑt steɪn ðə kɑɹpət wɪð ɪz blʌd, hænlən wəɾ it ðə buts stɪkɪŋ aʊt fɹəm wʌn ɛnd.

As expected, the front sitting room had a fine blaze burning away in the wide fireplace of blue-veined marble. It was a room worth the looting, with Sea Folk porcelain vases on the gilt-edged side tables, and tapestries and carpets that would fetch a pretty price. Except that one of the carpets was likely worthless, now. A low blanket-covered mound lay near the middle of the room, and if the fellow that made it had not stained the carpet with his blood, Hanlon would eat the boots sticking out from one end.

ʃieɪn hɝsɛlf wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə kɑɹvd ɑɹmtʃɛɹ, ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən ɪn ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu sɪlk wɪð ən ɔɹneɪt bɛlt ʌv woʊvən ɡoʊld ən ə hɛvi ɡoʊl nɛkləs ɝaʊn əɹ slɪm nɛk. ɡlɔsi bɹaʊn hɛɹ hʌŋ bɪloʊ hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ivən kɑɾ ɪn ə nɛɾ ʌv ɪntʃɹəkət leɪs. ʃi lʊk dɛləkəɾ ət fɝst ɡlæns, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ vʌlpaɪn əbaʊɾ əɹ feɪs, ən əɹ smaɪl nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ðoʊz bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz. ʃi wɑz juzɪŋ ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf tə klin ə smɔl dæɡɝ kæpt wɪð ə faɪɝdʒɹɑp ɑn ðə pɑməl. "ɡoʊ tɛl mɹɛlɪn ðəɾ əl əv ə . . . bʌndəl . . . fəɹ ɪm tə dɪspoʊz ə leɪɾɝ, fæljən," ʃi sɛd kɑmli.

Shiaine herself was sitting in a carved armchair, a pretty woman in gold-embroidered blue silk with an ornate belt of woven gold and a heavy gold necklace around her slim neck. Glossy brown hair hung below her shoulders even caught in a net of intricate lace. She looked delicate at first glance, but there was something vulpine about her face, and her smile never touched those big brown eyes. She was using a lace-edged handkerchief to clean a small dagger capped with a firedrop on the pommel. "Go tell Murellin that I will have a . . . bundle . . . for him to dispose of later, Falion," she said calmly.

fæljənz feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð əz pɑlɪʃt mɑɹbəl, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ ə kɝtsi ðət læk lɪɾəl ə kɹɪŋɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi skʌɾəld aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum əɾ ə ɹʌn.

Falion's face remained smooth as polished marble, but she made a curtsy that lacked little of cringing before she scuttled out of the room at a run.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊmən ən əɹ dæɡɝ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, hænlən muv tə ðə kʌvɝd maʊn ən bɛn tə lɪft ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə blæŋkət. ɡleɪz blu aɪz stɛɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə feɪs ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn hɑɹd, əlaɪv. ðə dɛɾ ɔlweɪz lʊk sɑftɝ. əpɛɹənli hi hæd bɪn niðɝ əz kɔʃəs nɔɹ əz ɪntɛlədʒən əz fæljən θɔt hɪm. hænlən lɛt ðə blæŋkət fɔl ən stʃɹeɪɾənd. "hi sɛd sʌmθɪŋ jə əbdʒɛktəd tə, maɪ leɪɾi?" hi sɛd maɪldli. "hu wɑz hi?" "hi sɛd sɛvɹəl θɪŋz aɪ əbdʒɛktəd tə." ʃi hɛld əɹ dæɡɝ ʌp, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə smɔl bleɪd tə bi ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz klin, ðən slɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ə ɡoʊld-wɝkt ʃiθ əɾ əɹ weɪst.

Watching the woman and her dagger from the corner of his eye, Hanlon moved to the covered mound and bent to lift a corner of the blanket. Glazed blue eyes stared out of a face that might have been hard, alive. The dead always looked softer. Apparently he had been neither as cautious nor as intelligent as Falion thought him. Hanlon let the blanket fall and straightened. "He said something you objected to, my Lady?" he said mildly. "Who was he?" "He said several things I objected to." She held her dagger up, studying the small blade to be sure it was clean, then slid it into a gold-worked sheath at her waist.

"tɛl mi, ɪz ɪleɪnz tʃaɪl jʊɹz?" "aɪ doʊnt noʊ hu fɑðɝd ðə wɛlp," hi sɛd ɹaɪli. "waɪ, maɪ leɪɾi? dʒju θɪŋk aɪd ɡoʊ sɑft? ðə læs tʃɪɾ u kleɪmd aɪd ɡɑɾən ə tʃaɪld ɑn hɝ, aɪ stʌft əɹ daʊn ə wɛl tə kul əɹ hɛɾ ən meɪd ʃʊɹ ʃi steɪd ðɛɹ." ðəɹ wɝ ə lɔŋ-nɛk sɪlvɝ waɪn pɪtʃɝ ən tu tʃeɪst sɪlvɝ kʌps sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ ɑn wʌn ə ðə saɪd teɪbəlz. "ɪz ðɪs seɪf?" hi æskt, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə kʌps. boʊθ hæd waɪn ɪn ðə bɑɾəm, bʌɾ ə lɪɾəl ədɪʃən tə wʌn wʊɾə tɝn ðə dɛd mæn ɪndə izi pɹeɪ.

"Tell me, is Elayne's child yours?" "I don't know who fathered the whelp," he said wryly. "Why, my Lady? Do you think I'd go soft? The last chit who claimed I'd gotten a child on her, I stuffed her down a well to cool her head and made sure she stayed there." There were a long-necked silver wine pitcher and two chased silver cups sitting on a tray on one of the side tables. "Is this safe?" he asked, peering into the cups. Both had wine in the bottom, but a little addition to one would have turned the dead man into easy prey.

"kætʃɹɛl moʊsənən, ən aɪɝənmɑŋɡɝz dɔɾɝ fɹəm mɹoʊn," ðə wʊmən sɛd, dʒʌst əz smuðli əz ɪf ɪt wɝ kɑmən nɑlədʒ, ən i vɛɹi nɪɹli flɪntʃt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ju splɪɾ əɹ hɛɾ oʊpən wɪð ə ɹɑk bɪfɔɹ jə pɪtʃt əɹ daʊn, noʊ daʊt tə spɛɹ əɹ dʒɹaʊnɪŋ." haʊ dɪd ʃi noʊ ðə wɛnks neɪm, mʌtʃ lɛs əbaʊt ðə ɹɑk? hi hæd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ neɪm hɪmsɛlf. "noʊ, aɪ daʊt jə wəd ɡoʊ sɑft, bʌɾ aɪ wəd heɪt tə θɪŋk jə wɝ kɪsɪŋ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ mi noʊ. aɪ wəd pjʊɹli heɪt ðæt."

"Catrelle Mosenain, an ironmonger's daughter from Maerone," the woman said, just as smoothly as if it were common knowledge, and he very nearly flinched in surprise. "You split her head open with a rock before you pitched her down, no doubt to spare her drowning." How did she know the wench's name, much less about the rock? He had not remembered her name himself. "No, I doubt you would go soft, but I would hate to think you were kissing the Lady Elayne without letting me know. I would purely hate that."

sʌɾənli ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə blʌdsteɪn hæŋkɝtʃɪf ɪn əɹ hæn ən ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli tə ɡlaɪd tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən tɔs ɪɾ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. ʃi stʊd ðəɹ wɔɹmɪŋ hɝsɛlf, nɛvɝ ivən ɡlænsɪŋ ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. "kæn jə ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ səm ə ðə sintʃæn wɪmən tə ɪskeɪp? bɛst ɪf ɪt kən bi boʊθ ðoʊz kɔl sʌldəm ən ðə wʌnz kɔl deɪmeɪn" ʃi stʌmbəld ə lɪɾəl oʊvɝ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝdz, "bʌɾ ɪf jə kæn də boʊθ, ðən ə fju ʌv ðə sʌldəm ʃəd du. ðəl fɹi səm ə ði ʌðɝz."

Suddenly she frowned at the bloodstained handkerchief in her hand and rose gracefully to glide to the fireplace and toss it into the flames. She stood there warming herself, never even glancing in his direction. "Can you arrange for some of the Seanchan women to escape? Best if it can be both those called sul'dam and the ones called damane" she stumbled a little over the strange words, "but if you can't do both, then a few of the sul'dam should do. They will free some of the others."

"meɪbi." blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, ʃi wɑz dænsɪŋ fɹəm wʌn θɪŋ tə ənʌðɝ wɝs ðən fæljən tənaɪt. "ɪt woʊn bi izi, maɪ leɪɾi. ðəɹ ɔl ɡɑɹɾəd kloʊs."

"Maybe." Blood and bloody ashes, she was dancing from one thing to another worse than Falion tonight. "It won't be easy, my Lady. They're all guarded close."

"aɪ dɪdn æsk wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz izi," ʃi sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. "kæn jə ʃɪft ɡɑɹdz əweɪ fɹəm ðə fud wɛɹhaʊzɪz? ɪt wəd pliz mi ɪf səm ə ðoʊz æktʃəli  aɪm æm taɪɝɾ ʌv ətɛmps ðəɾ ɔlweɪz feɪl."

"I didn't ask whether it was easy," she said, staring into the flames. "Can you shift guards away from the food warehouses? It would please me if some of those actually burned. I am tired of attempts that always fail."

"ðæɾ aɪ kænɑt du," hi mʌɾɝd. "nɑɾ ənlɛs jə ɪkspɛk mi tə ɡoʊ ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ ɹaɪɾ æftɝ. ðeɪ kip ə ɹɛkɝɾ ʌv ɔɹɾɝz ðət wəd meɪk ə kɛɹhinɪn wɪns. ən ɪt wʊdn də ɛni ɡʊɾ ɛniweɪ, nɑt wɪð ðoʊz blʌɾi ɡeɪtweɪz bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn mɔɹ wæɡənz ɛvɹi blʌɾi deɪ." ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz nɑt sɑɹi fəɹ ðæt. kwizi oʊvɝ ðə minz juzd, sɝɾənli, bʌt nɑt sɑɹi. hi ɪkspɛktəd ðə pæləs wəd bi ðə læs pleɪs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn tə ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi ɪn ɛni keɪs, bʌɾ i hæd lɪvd aʊt sidʒəz ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə laɪnz, ən i hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɛvɝ bɔɪlɪŋ ɪz buts fəɹ sup əɡɛn. ʃieɪn wɑntəd faɪɝz, ðoʊ.

"That I cannot do," he muttered. "Not unless you expect me to go into hiding right after. They keep a record of orders that would make a Cairhienin wince. And it wouldn't do any good anyway, not with those bloody gateways bringing in more wagons every bloody day." In truth, he was not sorry for that. Queasy over the means used, certainly, but not sorry. He expected the palace would be the last place in Caemlyn to go hungry in any case, but he had lived out sieges on both sides of the lines, and he had no intention of ever boiling his boots for soup again. Shiaine wanted fires, though.

"ənʌðɝ ænsɝ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ æsk fɔɹ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, stɪl lʊkɪŋ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, nɑɾ ət hɪm. "bʌt pɝhæps sʌmθɪŋ kən bi dʌn ðɛɹ. haʊ kloʊs ɑɹ jə tə æktʃəli  . . . ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ɪleɪnz əfɛkʃənz?" ʃi fɪnɪʃt pɹɪmli.

"Another answer I did not ask for." She shook her head, still looking into the fireplace, not at him. "But perhaps something can be done there. How close are you to actually . . . enjoying Elayne's affections?" she finished primly.

"kloʊsɝ ðən ðə deɪ aɪ ɝaɪvd ɪn ðə pæləs," hi ɡɹaʊld, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ əɾ əɹ bæk. hi tʃɹaɪd nɛvɝ tə əfɛn ðoʊz ðə tʃoʊzən hæd sɛɾ əbʌv hɪm, bʌt ðə tʃɪt wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɪm. hi kəd snæp ðət slɛndɝ nɛk laɪk ə twɪɡ! tə kip ɪz hænz fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt, hi fɪld wʌn ə ðə kʌps ən hɛld ɪt wɪð noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. ɪn ɪz lɛf hænd, ʌv kɔɹs. dʒʌs kəz ðəɹ wɑz wʌn dɛd mæn ɪn ðə ɹum ɔlɹɛɾi dɪd nɑt min ʃi hæd noʊ plænz tə meɪk ɪt tu kɔɹpsəz. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ sloʊ. ɪɾ ɪzən əz ɪf aɪ kən bæk əɹ ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ ən tɪkəl əɹ aʊɾ ə hɝ ʃɪft."

"Closer than the day I arrived in the palace," he growled, glowering at her back. He tried never to offend those the Chosen had set above him, but the chit was trying him. He could snap that slender neck like a twig! To keep his hands from her throat, he filled one of the cups and held it with no intention of drinking. In his left hand, of course. Just because there was one dead man in the room already did not mean she had no plans to make it two corpses. "But I have to go slow. It isn't as if I can back her into a corner and tickle her out of her shift."

"aɪ səpoʊz nɑt," ʃieɪn sɛɾ ɪn ə mʌfəl vɔɪs. "ʃi ɪz hɑɹdli ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊmən jə ɑɹ juz tə." wɑz ʃi læfɪŋ! wɑz ʃi əmjuzd ət hɪm? ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də nɑt tə θɹoʊ daʊn ðə waɪnkʌp ən stʃɹæŋɡəl ðə fɑks-feɪs bɪnt.

"I suppose not," Shiaine said in a muffled voice. "She is hardly the sort of woman you are used to." Was she laughing! Was she amused at him? It was all he could do not to throw down the winecup and strangle the fox-faced bint.

sʌɾənli ʃi tɝn ɝaʊnd, ən i blɪŋkt əz ʃi kæʒəwəli slɪpt əɹ dæɡɝ bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ dʒɹɔ ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ! hi tʊk ə swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, ən ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt wən i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. "haʊ wəd jə laɪk tə si keɪɛmlɪn luɾəd?" ʃi æskt. "wɛl ɪnʌf, ɪf aɪ hæv ə ɡʊd kʌmpəni ət maɪ bæk ən ə klɪɹ pæθ tə ðə ɡeɪts." ðə waɪn hæd tə bi seɪf. tu kʌps mɛnt ʃi hæd dʒɹʌŋk, tu, ən ɪf i hæd pɪkt ʌp ðə dɛd mænz, ðəɹ kəd nɑt bi ɪnʌf pɔɪzən lɛft ɪn ɪt tə sɪkən ə maʊs. "ɪz ðət wʌt jə wɑnt? aɪ fɑloʊ ɔɹɾɝz əz wɛl əz ðə nɛks mæn." hi dɪd wən i sim laɪkli tə sɝvaɪv ðɛm, əɹ wən ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm ðə tʃoʊzən. əz wɛl daɪ fəɹ ə ful əz dɪsəbeɪ ðə tʃoʊzən. "bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt hɛlps tə noʊ mɔɹ ðən 'ɡoʊ ðəɹ ən də ðæt.' ɪf jə toʊl mi wʌt jəɹ æftɝ hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə hɛlp jə ɹitʃ ɪt fæstɝ."

Suddenly she turned around, and he blinked as she casually slipped her dagger back into its sheath. He had never seen her draw the bloody thing! He took a swallow of wine without thinking, and almost choked when he realized what he had done. "How would you like to see Caemlyn looted?" she asked. "Well enough, if I have a good company at my back and a clear path to the gates." The wine had to be safe. Two cups meant she had drunk, too, and if he had picked up the dead man's, there could not be enough poison left in it to sicken a mouse. "Is that what you want? I follow orders as well as the next man." He did when he seemed likely to survive them, or when they came from the Chosen. As well die for a fool as disobey the Chosen. "But sometimes it helps to know more than 'go there and do that.' If you told me what you're after here in Caemlyn, I might be able to help you reach it faster."

"ʌv kɔɹs." ʃi smaɪld ə tuθi smaɪl waɪl əɹ aɪz steɪɾ əz flæɾ əz bɹaʊn stoʊnz. "bʌt fɝst, tɛl mi waɪ ðəɹ ɪz fɹɛʃ blʌɾ ɑn jəɹ ɡɔnlət?"

"Of course." She smiled a toothy smile while her eyes stayed as flat as brown stones. "But first, tell me why there is fresh blood on your gauntlet?"

hi smaɪl bæk. "ə fʊtpæɾ u ɡɑɾ ənlʌki, maɪ leɪɾi." meɪbi ʃi hæd sɛn ðə mæn ən meɪbi nɑt, bʌɾ i æɾəd əɹ θɹoʊt tə ðə lɪst ə ðoʊz i ɪntɛndəd tə slɪt. ən i maɪɾ əz wɛl æd mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn, tu. æftɝ ɔl, ə loʊn sɝvaɪvɝ wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u kəd tɛl ðə teɪl ʌv wʌt hæd hæpənd.

He smiled back. "A footpad who got unlucky, my Lady." Maybe she had sent the man and maybe not, but he added her throat to the list of those he intended to slit. And he might as well add Marillin Gemalphin, too. After all, a lone survivor was the only one who could tell the tale of what had happened.

tʃæptɝ sɪkstin

CHAPTER 16

ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn sæɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, livɪŋ ðə nɪɹɝ saɪɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn stɪl ɹæpt ɪn ʃædoʊz, bʌt ðə snoʊ ðət kʌvɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡlim bɹaɪtli. ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf sim tə ʃaɪn bɪhaɪn ɪts lɔŋ waɪt wɔlz, ɔl bɹeɪvli taʊɝɾ ən bænɝd, jɛt tə ɛɡwin, sɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk əbʌv ðə sɪɾi, ɪt simd ivən fɑɹðɝ əweɪ ðən ɪt ɹɪli wɑz. ði ɛɹɪnɪn waɪɾənd tə mɔɹ ðən tu maɪlz hɪɹ, ən ði əlɪndʒɹɛl ɛɹɪnɪn ən oʊsəndʒɹɛl ɛɹɪnɪn, floʊɪŋ tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ði aɪlənd, wɝ ɔlmoʊs hæf ðæt, soʊ ðət tɑɹ vəlɑn əpɪɹd tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt leɪk, ənɹitʃəbəl dɪspaɪt ðə mæsɪv bɹɪdʒəz ðət stʊd haɪ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝz soʊ ðət ʃɪps kəd seɪl bɪniθ əm izəli. ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, ə θɪk boʊn-waɪt ʃæft ɹaɪzɪŋ tə ən ɪmpɑsəbəl haɪt fɹəm ðə sɪɾiz hɑɹt, fɪld əɹ oʊn hɑɹt wɪð ə jɝnɪŋ fəɹ hoʊm. nɑt fəɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌt fəɹ ðə taʊɝ. ðət wɑz əɹ hoʊm, naʊ. ə plum ə smoʊk kɑɾ əɹ aɪ, ə feɪn blæk laɪn ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɑɹ bæŋk bɪɑn ðə sɪɾi, ən ʃi ɡɹɪməst. deɪʃɝ stæmpt ə huf ɪn ðə snoʊ, bʌɾ ə pæɾ ɑn ðə nɛk səfaɪs tə suð ðə ɹoʊn. ɪt wəd teɪk mɔɹ tə suð ɪz ɹaɪɾɝ. hoʊmsɪknəs wɑz ðə smɔləs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. mɪnəskjul, kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ɹɛst.

The Subject of Negotiations The morning sun sat on the horizon, leaving the nearer side of Tar Valon still wrapped in shadows, but the snow that covered everything gleamed brightly. The city itself seemed to shine behind its long white walls, all bravely towered and bannered, yet to Egwene, sitting her roan gelding on the riverbank above the city, it seemed even farther away than it really was. The Erinin widened to more than two miles here, and the Alindrelle Erinin and Osendrelle Erinin, flowing to either side of the island, were almost half that, so that Tar Valon appeared to sit in the middle of a great lake, unreachable despite the massive bridges that stood high above the waters so that ships could sail beneath them easily. The White Tower itself, a thick bone-white shaft rising to an impossible height from the city's heart, filled her own heart with a yearning for home. Not for the Two Rivers, but for the Tower. That was her home, now. A plume of smoke caught her eye, a faint black line rising from the far bank beyond the city, and she grimaced. Daishar stamped a hoof in the snow, but a pat on the neck sufficed to soothe the roan. It would take more to soothe his rider. Homesickness was the smallest part of it. Minuscule, compared to the rest.

wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi ɹɛstəɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz ɑn ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl ən ɹeɪz ðə lɔŋ bɹæsbaʊn lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. hɝ kloʊk fɛl bæk, slɪpɪŋ ɔf wʌn ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə koʊl ðət mɪstɪɾ əɹ bɹɛθ ən pleɪst ə ɡlʌv hæn tə ʃil ðə fɹʌn lɛnz əɡɛns ðə sʌnz ɡlɛɹ. ðə sɪɾi wɔlz lɛp kloʊsɝ ɪn əɹ saɪt. ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ðə tɔl kɝvɪŋ ɑɹmz ə nɔɹθhɑɹbɝ ðət pʊʃt aʊɾ ɪndə ði ʌpstʃɹim kɝəns. pipəl muv pɝpəsfəli ətɑp ðə bæɾəlmənts ðəɾ ɛnfoʊldəd ðə hɑɹbɝ, bʌt ʃi kəd bɛɹli dɪsɝn mɛn fɹəm wɪmən ət ðət dɪstəns. stɪl, ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ðət ʃi wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ əɹ sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl, ən ðəɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz dip wɪðɪn əɹ kaʊl, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs sʌmwʌn ðəɹ hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋɝ ɡlæs ðən ʃi. ðə waɪd maʊθ ə ðə mæn-meɪd hɑɹbɝ wɑz blɑk baɪ ə mæsɪv aɪɝn tʃeɪn dʒɹɔn tɔɾ ə fju fiɾ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ. taɪni dɑts ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ, daɪvɪŋ bɝdz fɪʃɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə hɑɹbɝ, ɡeɪv ðə tʃeɪn skeɪl. wʌn sɪŋɡəl peɪs-lɔŋ lɪŋk wʊɾə ɹikwaɪɝd tu mɛn tə lɪft ɪt. ə ɹoʊboʊt maɪt slɪp ʌndɝ ðət bæɹiɝ, bʌt noʊ vɛsəl ʌv ɛni saɪz wəɾ ɛntɝ ənlɛs ðə waɪt taʊɝ əlaʊd. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə tʃeɪn wɑz oʊnli ɪntɛndəd tə kip aʊɾ ɛnəmiz. "ðɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ, mʌðɝ," lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ mɝmɝd, ən ʃi loʊɝd ðə ɡlæs. hɝ dʒɛnɝəl wɑz ə stɑki mæn ɪn ə pleɪn bɹɛstpleɪt wɔɹn oʊvɝ ə pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊt, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɪlt əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɛniwɛɹ. hɪz feɪs wɑz blʌf ən wɛðɝd bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət, ən ðə jɪɹz hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ə stʃɹeɪnʒ sɔɹɾ ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ kɑmnəs. ɔl jə nid də wɑz lʊk ət ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn tə noʊ ðəɾ ɪf ðə pɪɾ ə dum oʊpən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, hi wəd smʌðɝ ɪz fɪɹ ən ɡoʊ əbaʊt duɪŋ wʌt niɾəd duɪŋ. ən ʌðɝ mɛn wəd fɑloʊ hɪm. hi hæd pɹuvd ɑn bæɾəlfild æftɝ bæɾəlfild ðət fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm wɑz ðə pæθ tə vɪktɝi. ə ɡʊd mæn tə hæv fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ. hɝ aɪz fɑloʊɾ ɪz ɡɔntələɾəd hænd, pɔɪntɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ.

With a sigh, she rested her reins on the high pommel of her saddle and raised the long brassbound looking glass. Her cloak fell back, slipping off one shoulder, but she ignored the cold that misted her breath and placed a gloved hand to shield the front lens against the sun's glare. The city walls leaped closer in her sight. She focused on the tall curving arms of Northharbor that pushed out into the upstream currents. People moved purposefully atop the battlements that enfolded the harbor, but she could barely discern men from women at that distance. Still, she was glad that she was not wearing her seven-striped stole, and that her face was deep within her cowl, just in case someone there had a stronger glass than she. The wide mouth of the man-made harbor was blocked by a massive iron chain drawn taut a few feet above the water. Tiny dots on the water, diving birds fishing in front of the harbor, gave the chain scale. One single pace-long link would have required two men to lift it. A rowboat might slip under that barrier, but no vessel of any size would enter unless the White Tower allowed. Of course, the chain was only intended to keep out enemies. "There they are, Mother," Lord Gareth murmured, and she lowered the glass. Her general was a stocky man in a plain breastplate worn over a plain brown coat, without any touch of gilt or embroidery anywhere. His face was bluff and weathered behind the bars of his helmet, and the years had given him a strange sort of comforting calmness. All you need do was look at Gareth Bryne to know that if the Pit of Doom opened in front of him, he would smother his fear and go about doing what needed doing. And other men would follow him. He had proved on battlefield after battlefield that following him was the path to victory. A good man to have following her. Her eyes followed his gauntleted hand, pointing upriver.

dʒʌs kʌmɪŋ ɪn saɪɾ ɝaʊn ə pɔɪn ə lænd, faɪv, sɪks - noʊ, sɛvən - ɹɪvɝʃɪps wɝ slaɪsɪŋ fɝoʊz daʊn ði ɛɹɪnɪn. lɑɹdʒ vɛsəlz əz sətʃ θɪŋz wɝ sin ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ, wʌn wɪð θɹi mæsts, ðɛɹ tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ seɪlz stʊɾ aʊt taɪt, ən ðɛɹ lɔŋ swips kʌt hɑɹd θɹu ðə blu-ɡɹin wɔɾɝ tə æɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ spid.

Just coming in sight around a point of land, five, six - no, seven - riverships were slicing furrows down the Erinin. Large vessels as such things were seen on the river, one with three masts, their triangular sails stood out tight, and their long sweeps cut hard through the blue-green water to add a little more speed.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɹæf spoʊk ʌv ə bɝnɪŋ dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ spid, ə dɪzaɪɝ tə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn naʊ!

Everything about the craft spoke of a burning desire for speed, a desire to reach Tar Valon now!

ðə ɹɪvɝ wɑz dip ɪnʌf hɪɹ ðət ʃɪps kəd ɹʌn wɪðɪn ʃaʊɾɪŋ dɪstəns ə ðə bæŋks ɪn pleɪsəz, bʌt ðiz seɪld ɪn ɔlmoʊst sɪŋɡəl faɪl əz kloʊs tə ðə mɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹɪnɪn əz ðə stɪɹsmɪn kəd mænədʒ ən hoʊl ðə wɪnd. seɪlɝz klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə mæsθhɛdz kɛpt wɑtʃ əlɔŋ ðə ʃɔɹlaɪn, ən nɑt fəɹ mʌdbæŋks.

The river was deep enough here that ships could run within shouting distance of the banks in places, but these sailed in almost single file as close to the middle of the Erinin as the steersmen could manage and hold the wind. Sailors clinging to the mastheads kept watch along the shoreline, and not for mudbanks.

ɪn fækt, ðeɪ hæd nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl tə fɪɹ soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kɛpt aʊɾ ə baʊʃɑt. tʃɹu, fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi sæɾ əɹ hɔɹs, ʃi cʊɾə sɛt faɪɝ tə ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz ʃɪps, əɹ sɪmpli kʌt hoʊlz θɹu ðɛɹ hʌlz ən lɛɾ əm sɪŋk. ðə wɝk ə moʊməns. jɛt duɪŋ soʊ ʃʊɹli mɛn səm ə ðoʊz əbɔɹd wəd dʒɹaʊn.

In fact, they had nothing at all to fear so long as they kept out of bowshot. True, from where she sat her horse, she could have set fire to every one of those ships, or simply cut holes through their hulls and let them sink. The work of moments. Yet doing so surely meant some of those aboard would drown.

ðə kɝəns wɝ stʃɹɔŋ, ðə wɔɾɝ laɪk aɪs, ən ðə swɪm tə ʃɔɹ lɔŋ, fəɹ ðoʊz u æktʃəli  kəd swɪm. ivən wʌn dɛθ wəd meɪk wʌt ʃi dɪd juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪv əz ðoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi baʊn baɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz, ən ði oʊðz pɹətɛktəd ðoʊz vɛsəlz fɹəm əɹ əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ. ə sɪstɝ u hæd swɔɹn ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə meɪk hɝsɛlf sɛt ðoʊz wivz, pɝhæps nɑɾ ivən tə fɔɹm ðɛm, ənlɛs ʃi kəd kənvɪns hɝsɛlf ʃi wɑz ɪn ɪmiɾiət deɪnʒɝ fɹəm ðə ʃɪps. bʌt niðɝ kæptənz nɔɹ kɹuz bɪliv ðæt, əpɛɹənli.

The currents were strong, the water like ice, and the swim to shore long, for those who actually could swim. Even one death would make what she did using the Power as a weapon. She was trying to live as though already bound by the Three Oaths, and the Oaths protected those vessels from her or any other sister. A sister who had sworn on the Oath Rod would not be able to make herself set those weaves, perhaps not even to form them, unless she could convince herself she was in immediate danger from the ships. But neither captains nor crews believed that, apparently.

əz ðə ɹɪvɝʃɪps keɪm kloʊsɝ, ʃaʊts θɪn tə θɹɛdbɛɹ baɪ dɪstəns dʒɹɪftəɾ əkɹɔs ðə wɔɾɝ.

As the riverships came closer, shouts thinned to threadbare by distance drifted across the water.

ðə lʊkaʊts ʌp ɑn ðə mæsts pɔɪntəd tə hɝ ən ɡɛɹɪθ, ən ɪt kwɪkli bɪkeɪm əpɛɹən ðeɪ tʊk əɹ fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. əɹ ət list, ðə kæptənz wɝ ənwɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ðə tʃæns ʃi wɑz nɑt. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðə biɾ ə ðə swips ɪnkɹist. oʊnli baɪ ə fɹækʃən, bʌt ði ɔɹsmɪn leɪbɝd tə faɪn ðət fɹækʃən. ə wʊmən ɑn ðə kɔɹɾɝdɛk ə ðə lɛd vɛsəl, laɪkli ðə kæptən, weɪvd əɹ ɑɹmz əz ɪf dɪmændɪŋ stɪl mɔɹ ɛfɝt, ən ə hændfʊl ə mɛn bɪɡæn ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə dɛk, taɪɾənɪŋ ðɪs laɪn əɹ lusənɪŋ ðət tə tʃeɪnʒ ði æŋɡəl ə ðə seɪlz, ðoʊ ɛɡwin kəd nɑt si ðət ðeɪ ətʃivd ɛniθɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ mɛn ɑn ðoʊz dɛks ʌðɝ ðən seɪlɝz, ən moʊst ə ðoʊz kɹaʊɾəd tə ðə ɹeɪlɪŋz, ə hændfʊl ɹeɪzɪŋ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz ə ðɛɹ oʊn. səm sim tə bi mɛʒɝɪŋ ðə dɪstəns lɛf tə kʌvɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə seɪfti ʌv ðə hɑɹbɝ. ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt wivɪŋ ə flɛɹ, ə stɑɹbɝst ə laɪt, pɝhæps wɪð ə laʊd bæŋ, dʒʌst əbʌv itʃ ə ðə vɛsəlz. ðət wəd sɝɾənli lɛɾ ɛniwʌn əbɔɹd wɪð bɹeɪnz ɹilaɪz ðət niðɝ spid nɔɹ dɪstəns kɛpt əm seɪf hɪɹ, oʊnli ə fɔɹbɛɹəns bɔɹn ə ðə θɹi oʊðz. ðeɪ ʃəd noʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ seɪf kəz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ.

The lookouts up on the masts pointed to her and Gareth, and it quickly became apparent they took her for an Aes Sedai with her Warder. Or at least, the captains were unwilling to take the chance she was not. After a moment, the beat of the sweeps increased. Only by a fraction, but the oarsmen labored to find that fraction. A woman on the quarterdeck of the lead vessel, likely the captain, waved her arms as if demanding still more effort, and a handful of men began running up and down the deck, tightening this line or loosening that to change the angle of the sails, though Egwene could not see that they achieved anything. There were men on those decks other than sailors, and most of those crowded to the railings, a handful raising looking glasses of their own. Some seemed to be measuring the distance left to cover before they reached the safety of the harbor. She thought about weaving a flare, a starburst of light, perhaps with a loud bang, just above each of the vessels. That would certainly let anyone aboard with brains realize that neither speed nor distance kept them safe here, only a forbearance born of the Three Oaths. They should know that they were safe because of Aes Sedai.

ɪkshəlɪŋ hɛvəli, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ən mɛntəli əpbɹeɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf. ðət sɪmpəl wiv wəɾ ɔlsoʊ ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən ɪn ðə sɪɾi, sɝɾənli mɔɹ ðən ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl sɪstɝ. sɪstɝz ɔfən keɪm tə ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk tə stɛɹ ət tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ðə taʊɝ. ivən ɪf ði oʊnli ɹiækʃən tə hɝ flɛɹz wɑz səm sɔɹɾ ə kaʊntɝɾɪspleɪ, wʌns bɪɡʌn, ðət sɔɹɾ ə kɑntɛs kəd bi vɛɹi dɪfəkəl tə pʊɾ ə stɑp tə. wʌns bɪɡʌn, mæɾɝz maɪt wɛl ɛskəleɪɾ aʊɾ ə hænd. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni ɑpɝtunəɾiz fəɹ ðæt, əz ɪt wɑz, ðə mɔɹ soʊ ðiz læs faɪv deɪz.

Exhaling heavily, she shook her head and mentally upbraided herself. That simple weave would also attract attention in the city, certainly more than the appearance of a single sister. Sisters often came to the riverbank to stare at Tar Valon and the Tower. Even if the only reaction to her flares was some sort of counterdisplay, once begun, that sort of contest could be very difficult to put a stop to. Once begun, matters might well escalate out of hand. There were too many opportunities for that, as it was, the more so these last five days.

"ðə hɑɹbɔɹmæstɝ hæzən lɛɾ əbʌv eɪɾ əɹ naɪn ʃɪps ɪn ət wʌn taɪm sɪns wi ɝaɪvd," ɡɛɹɪθ sɛɾ əz ðə fɝs vɛsəl dʒɹu əbɹɛst ə ðɛm, "bʌt ðə kæptənz sim tə hæv wɝkt aʊt ðə taɪmɪŋ.

"The harbormaster hasn't let above eight or nine ships in at one time since we arrived," Gareth said as the first vessel drew abreast of them, "but the captains seemed to have worked out the timing.

ənʌðɝ klʌtʃ wɪl əpɪɹ sun, ən ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi əbaʊt ðə taɪm ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz ɑɹ ʃʊɹ ðiz fɛloʊz æktʃəli  keɪm tə ɛnlɪst. dʒɪmɑɹ tʃʌbn noʊz ɪnʌf tə ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛns mi snikɪŋ mɛn ɪn əbɔɹd hiz hæz mɔɹ ə ðə ɡɑɹdz kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə ðə hɑɹbɝz ðən ɛniwɛɹ ɪksɛpt ət ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊɝz, ən nɑt mɛni ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪ kən lɝn. ðət wɪl tʃeɪnʒ, ðoʊ. ðə floʊ ʌv ʃɪps stɑɹts ət fɝs laɪɾ ən kips ʌp tɪl nɪɹ naɪtfɔl, hɪɹ ən ət saʊθhɑɹbɝ tu. ðɪs lɑt dʌzn sim tə bi kæɹiɪŋ əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz əz moʊs du. ɛvɹi plæn ɪz bɹɪljən əntɪl ðə deɪ kʌmz, mʌðɝ, bʌt ðən jə mʌst ədæp tə sɝkəmstænsəz əɹ bi ɹɪɾən daʊn."

Another clutch will appear soon, and reach the city about the time the Tower Guards are sure these fellows actually came to enlist. Jimar Chubain knows enough to guard against me sneaking men in aboard ships. He has more of the Guards crowded into the harbors than anywhere except at the bridge towers, and not many anywhere else, so far as I can learn. That will change, though. The flow of ships starts at first light and keeps up till near nightfall, here and at Southharbor too. This lot doesn't seem to be carrying as many soldiers as most do. Every plan is brilliant until the day comes, Mother, but then you must adapt to circumstances or be ridden down."

ɛɡwin meɪɾ ə vɛkst saʊnd. ðəɹ mʌs bi tu hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ pæsənʒɝz ɔltəɡɛðɝ ɑn ðoʊz sɛvən ʃɪps. ə fju maɪt bi mɝtʃəns əɹ tʃɹeɪɾɝz əɹ səm ʌðɝ sɔɹɾ ʌv ɪnəsən tʃɹævəlɝ, bʌt ðə loʊ sʌn ɡlɪɾɝd ɔf hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ən stil dɪsks soʊn tə lɛðɝ dʒɝkɪnz. haʊ mɛni ʃɪploʊdz ɝaɪvd itʃ deɪ? wʌtɛvɝ ðə nʌmbɝ, ə stɛɾi floʊ wɑz pɔɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi tə ɛnlɪst ʌndɝ haɪ kæptən tʃʌbn. "waɪ də mɛn ɔlweɪz ɹʌʃ soʊ hɑɹd tə kɪl əɹ bi kɪld?" ʃi mʌɾɝd ɪɹɪɾəbli. lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ lʊkt əɾ əɹ kɑmli. hi sæɾ ɪz hɔɹs, ə bɪɡ beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹaɪp daʊn ɪz noʊz, laɪk ə stætʃu. səmtaɪmz, ʃi θɔt ʃi nu wʌn smɔl pɑɹɾ ə haʊ sɪuən fɛlt əbaʊt ðə mæn. səmtaɪmz ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd bi wɝθ wʌtɛvɝ ɛfɝt wɑz niɾəd tə stɑɹɾəl hɪm, dʒʌs tə si hɪm stɑɹɾəld.

Egwene made a vexed sound. There must be two hundred or more passengers altogether on those seven ships. A few might be merchants or traders or some other sort of innocent traveler, but the low sun glittered off helmets and breastplates and steel discs sewn to leather jerkins. How many shiploads arrived each day? Whatever the number, a steady flow was pouring into the city to enlist under High Captain Chubain. "Why do men always rush so hard to kill or be killed?" she muttered irritably. Lord Gareth looked at her calmly. He sat his horse, a big bay gelding with a white stripe down his nose, like a statue. Sometimes, she thought she knew one small part of how Siuan felt about the man. Sometimes she thought it would be worth whatever effort was needed to startle him, just to see him startled.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi nu ði ænsɝ tə hɝ oʊn kwɛstʃən əz wɛl əz i dɪd. ət list əz ɪɾ əplaɪd tə mɛn ɡoʊɪŋ soʊlʒɝɪŋ. oʊ, ðəɹ wɝ mɛn ɪnʌf u ɹʌʃt tə səpɔɹɾ ə kɑz əɹ dɪfɛnd wʌt ðeɪ θɔt wʌt wɑz ɹaɪt, ən səm u sɔɾ ædvɛntʃɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ bɪliv ðət wɑz, jɛt ðə sɪmpəl fækt wɑz ðət fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ ə paɪk əɹ spɪɹ, ə mæn kəɾ ɝn twaɪs itʃ deɪ wʌɾ i wəd ɡɛt fəɹ wɔkɪŋ bɪhaɪn ənʌðɝ mænz plaʊ, ən hæf əɡɛn əz mʌtʃ ɪf i kəd ɹaɪd wɛl ɪnʌf tə dʒɔɪn ðə kævəlɹi. kɹɔsboʊmən ən ɑɹtʃɝz fɛl ɪn bɪtwin. ðə mæn u wɝk fəɹ ənʌðɝ kəd dʒɹim ə hævɪŋ ɪz oʊn fɑɹm əɹ ʃɑp wʌn deɪ, əɹ ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ təwɔɹd wʌn ðəɾ ɪz sʌnz kəd bɪld ɑn, bʌɾ i ʃʊɹli hæd hɝɾ ə θaʊzən teɪlz ə mɛn soʊlʒɝɪŋ fəɹ faɪv jɪɹz əɹ tɛn ən kʌmɪŋ hoʊm wɪð ɪnʌf ɡoʊl tə sɛt ðɛmsɛlvz ʌp ɪn kʌmfɝt, teɪlz ʌv ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɛn u ɹoʊz tə bɪkʌm dʒɛnɝəlz, əɹ lɔɹdz. fəɹ ə pʊɹ mæn, ɡɛɹɪθ hæd sɛd blʌnli, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðə pɔɪn ʌv ə paɪk kəd bi ə bɛɾɝ vju ðən ðə haɪn ɛn ə sʌmbɑɾi ɛlsəz plaʊ hɔɹs. ivən ɪf i wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ laɪkli tə daɪ fɹəm ðə paɪk ðən ɝn feɪm əɹ fɔɹtʃən. ə bɪɾɝ weɪ tə lʊk əɾ ɪt, jɛt ʃi ɪmædʒən ðət wɑz haʊ moʊst ə ðoʊz mɛn ɑn ðə ʃɪps sɔ mæɾɝz, tu. bʌt ðɛn, ðət wɑz haʊ ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən əɹ oʊn ɑɹmi. fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn u wɑntəd tə si ðə jusɝpɝ pʊl fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn u ivən nu fəɹ sɝɾən u ɪleɪɾə wɑz, tɛn ɪf nɑɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd hæd dʒɔɪn fəɹ ðə peɪ. səm ə ðə mɛn ɑn ðə ʃɪp wɝ ɹeɪzɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz, tə ʃoʊ ðə ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðə hɑɹbɝ wɔlz ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hoʊldɪŋ wɛpənz.

Unfortunately, she knew the answer to her own question as well as he did. At least as it applied to men going soldiering. Oh, there were men enough who rushed to support a cause or defend what they thought what was right, and some who sought adventure, whatever they believed that was, yet the simple fact was that for carrying a pike or spear, a man could earn twice each day what he would get for walking behind another man's plow, and half again as much if he could ride well enough to join the cavalry. Crossbowmen and archers fell in between. The man who worked for another could dream of having his own farm or shop one day, or a beginning toward one that his sons could build on, but he surely had heard a thousand tales of men soldiering for five years or ten and coming home with enough gold to set themselves up in comfort, tales of ordinary men who rose to become generals, or lords. For a poor man, Gareth had said bluntly, staring down the point of a pike could be a better view than the hind end of somebody else's plow horse. Even if he was far more likely to die from the pike than earn fame or fortune. A bitter way to look at it, yet she imagined that was how most of those men on the ships saw matters, too. But then, that was how she had gotten her own army. For every man who wanted to see the usurper pulled from the Amyrlin Seat, for every man who even knew for certain who Elaida was, ten if not a hundred had joined for the pay. Some of the men on the ship were raising their hands, to show the guards on the harbor walls they were not holding weapons.

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd, ən lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ saɪd. hɪz vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn kɑm, bʌɾ ɪz wɝdz wɝ hɑɹdli kʌmfɝɾɪŋ wən i spoʊk. "mʌðɝ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə hɑɹbɝz ɹɪmeɪn oʊpən, tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪl it bɛɾɝ ðən wi du, ən ɹæðɝ ðən ɡɹoʊɪŋ wikɝ wɪð hʌŋɡɝ, ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹd wɪl ɡɹoʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ən stʃɹɔŋɝ. aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊt ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɪl lɛt tʃʌbn ɹʌʃ aʊt tə ətæk ʌs, əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ wɪʃ i wʊd. ɛvɹi deɪ jə weɪɾ oʊnli ædz tə ðə bʊtʃɝz bɪl wɪl əv tə peɪ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. aɪv sɛd fɹəm ðə stɑɹɾ ɪɾəl kʌm tə ən əsɔlt, ɪn ði ɛnd, ən ðət hæzən tʃeɪnʒd, bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls hæz. hæv ðə sɪstɝz pʊt mi ən maɪ mɛn ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz naʊ, ən aɪ kən teɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪt woʊn bi klin. ɪt nɛvɝ ɪz. bʌɾ aɪ kən teɪk ðə sɪɾi fəɹ ju. ən fjuɝ wɪl daɪ ðən ɪf jə dɪleɪ."

"No," she said, and Lord Gareth sighed. His voice remained calm, but his words were hardly comforting when he spoke. "Mother, so long as the harbors remain open, Tar Valon will eat better than we do, and rather than growing weaker with hunger, the Tower Guard will grow larger and stronger. I very much doubt that Elaida will let Chubain rush out to attack us, as much as I wish he would. Every day you wait only adds to the butcher's bill we'll have to pay sooner or later. I've said from the start it will come to an assault, in the end, and that hasn't changed, but everything else has. Have the sisters put me and my men inside the walls now, and I can take Tar Valon. It won't be clean. It never is. But I can take the city for you. And fewer will die than if you delay."

ə nɑt fɔɹmd ɪn əɹ bɛli, twɪstəd taɪt tɪl ʃi kəd hɑɹdli bɹið. kɛɹfəli, stɛp baɪ stɛp, ʃi pɝfɔɹm nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪzəz tə meɪk ɪt lusən. ðə bæŋk kənteɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, ɡaɪɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ.

A knot formed in her belly, twisted tight till she could hardly breathe. Carefully, step by step, she performed novice exercises to make it loosen. The bank contained the river, guiding without controlling.

kɑm sɛɾəld ɑn hɝ, ɪn hɝ.

Calm settled on her, in her.

tu mɛni pipəl hæd bɪɡʌn siɪŋ ðə jusəz ʌv ɡeɪtweɪz, ən ɪn ə weɪ, ɡɛɹɪθ ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd ðə wɝst. hɪz bɪznəs wɑz wɔɹ, ən i wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪt. əz sun əz i lɝn ə ɡeɪtweɪ kəd teɪk mɔɹ ðən ə smɔl ɡɹup ə pipəl ət wʌn taɪm, hi hæd sin ði ɪmpləkeɪʃənz. ivən ðə ɡɹeɪt wɔlz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, bɪɑn ðə ɹeɪnʒ ʌv ɛni sidʒ kæɾəpʌlt nɑɾ ɑn ə bɑɹdʒ, ən wɝkt wɪð ðə paʊɝ tɪl ðə lɑɹdʒəs kæɾəpʌlt kəd nɑt mɑɹk əm ɪn ɛni keɪs, maɪɾ əz wɛl bi meɪɾ ə peɪpɝ əɡɛnst ən ɑɹmi ðət kəd tʃɹævəl. bʌt wɛðɝ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd lɝn əɹ nɑt, ʌðɝ mɛn wəd siz ɑn ðəɾ aɪdiə. ði æʃəmən ɔlɹɛɾi hæd, ɪt simd. wɔɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ʌɡli, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz gɑnə ɡɹoʊ ʌɡliɝ. "noʊ," ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd. "aɪ noʊ pipəl ɑɹ gɑnə daɪ bɪfɔɹ ðɪs ɪz oʊvɝ." ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ʃi kəd si ðɛm daɪɪŋ dʒʌs baɪ kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz. ivən mɔɹ wəd daɪ ɪf ʃi meɪd ðə ɹɔŋ dɪsɪʒənz, ðoʊ, ən nɑt dʒʌs hɪɹ. "bʌɾ aɪ hæv tə kip ðə waɪt taʊɝ əlaɪv - əɡɛns tɑɹmən ɡdən - tə stæn bɪtwin ðə wɝld ən ði æʃəmən - ən ðə taʊɝ wɪl daɪ ɪf ðɪs kʌmz tə sɪstɝz kɪlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn." ðət hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæpənd wʌns. ɪt kəd nɑt bi əlaʊɾ ə sɛkən taɪm. "ɪf ðə waɪt taʊɝ daɪz, hoʊp daɪz. aɪ ʃʊdn əv tə tɛl jə ðəɾ əɡɛn." deɪʃɝ snɔɹɾɪd ən tɔst ɪz hɛd, lʌnʒɪŋ əz ðoʊ hi hæd sɛnst əɹ ɪɹɪteɪʃən, bʌt ʃi ɹeɪn ɪm ɪn fɝmli ən slɪp ðə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs ɪndə ðə tuld lɛðɝ keɪs hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl.

Too many people had begun seeing the uses of gateways, and in a way, Gareth represented the worst. His business was war, and he was very good at it. As soon as he learned a gateway could take more than a small group of people at one time, he had seen the implications. Even the great walls of Tar Valon, beyond the range of any siege catapult not on a barge, and worked with the Power till the largest catapult could not mark them in any case, might as well be made of paper against an army that could Travel. But whether Gareth Bryne had learned or not, other men would seize on that idea. The Asha'man already had, it seemed. War had always been ugly, yet it was going to grow uglier. "No," she repeated. "I know people are going to die before this is over." The Light help her, she could see them dying just by closing her eyes. Even more would die if she made the wrong decisions, though, and not just here. "But I have to keep the White Tower alive - against Tarmon Gai'don - to stand between the world and the Asha'man - and the Tower will die if this comes to sisters killing one another in the streets of Tar Valon." That had already happened once. It could not be allowed a second time. "If the White Tower dies, hope dies. I shouldn't have to tell you that again." Daishar snorted and tossed his head, lunging as though he had sensed her irritation, but she reined him in firmly and slipped the looking glass into the tooled leather case hanging from her saddle.

ðə daɪvɪŋ bɝdz ɡeɪv ʌp ðɛɹ fɪʃɪŋ ən spɹæŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ əz ðə θɪk tʃeɪn ðət blɑk nɔɹθhɑɹbɝ bɪɡæn tə dʒɹup. ɪt wəd dɪp bɪniθ ðə sɝfəs wɛl bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst ʃɪp ɹitʃt ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊθ.

The diving birds gave up their fishing and sprang into the air as the thick chain that blocked Northharbor began to droop. It would dip beneath the surface well before the first ship reached the harbor mouth.

haʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ hæɾ ɪt bɪn ðət ʃi ɹitʃt tɑɹ vəlɑn baɪ ðət seɪm ɹut? ɔlmoʊs bɪɑn mɛmɹi, ɪt simd. ən eɪdʒ ɡɔn. ɪt hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ wʊmən u keɪm əʃɔɹ ən wɑz mɛt baɪ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz.

How long ago had it been that she reached Tar Valon by that same route? Almost beyond memory, it seemed. An Age gone. It had been another woman who came ashore and was met by the Mistress of Novices.

ɡɛɹɪθ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd wɪð ə kwɪk ɡɹɪmɑs. bʌt ðɛn, hi nɛvɝ ɡeɪv ʌp, dɪd hi? "ju hæv tə kip ðə waɪt taʊɝ əlaɪv, mʌðɝ, bʌt maɪ dʒɑb ɪz tə ɡɪv ɪt tə ju. ənlɛs θɪŋz əv tʃeɪnʒd ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt. aɪ kən si sɪstɝz wɪspɝɪŋ ən lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ivən ɪf aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz. ɪf jə stɪl wɑn ðə taʊɝ, ɪɾəl kʌm tə ən əsɔlt, bɛɾɝ sun ðən leɪt." sʌɾənli ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sim dɑɹkɝ, əz ðoʊ klaʊdz hæɾ əbskjʊɹd ðə sʌn. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd, ðə dɛd wɝ gɑnə paɪl ʌp laɪk kɔɹdwʊd, bʌt ʃi hæd tə kip ðə waɪt taʊɝ əlaɪv. ʃi hæd tə.

Gareth shook his head with a quick grimace. But then, he never gave up, did he? "You have to keep the White Tower alive, Mother, but my job is to give it to you. Unless things have changed that I don't know about. I can see sisters whispering and looking over their shoulders even if I don't know what it means. If you still want the Tower, it will come to an assault, better soon than late." Suddenly the morning seemed darker, as though clouds had obscured the sun. Whatever she did, the dead were going to pile up like cordwood, but she had to keep the White Tower alive. She had to.

wən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɡʊd tʃɔɪsəz, jə hæd tə tʃuz ðə wʌn ðət sim list ɹɔŋ.

When there were no good choices, you had to choose the one that seemed least wrong.

"aɪv sin ɪnʌf hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. wɪð wʌn læst ɡlæns ət ðət nɛɹoʊ laɪn ə smoʊk bɪɑn ðə sɪɾi, ʃi tɝn deɪʃɝ təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bæk fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ, wɛɹ əɹ ɛskɔɹt weɪɾəd əmʌŋ ði ɛvɝɡɹin lɛðɝlif ən wɪntɝ-bɛɹ bitʃ ən bɝtʃ.

"I've seen enough here," she said quietly. With one last glance at that narrow line of smoke beyond the city, she turned Daishar toward the trees a hundred paces back from the river, where her escort waited among the evergreen leatherleaf and winter-bare beech and birch.

tu hʌnʒɹəd laɪt kævəlɹi, ɪn bɔɪld lɛðɝ bɹɛstpleɪts əɹ koʊts kʌvɝd wɪð mɛɾəl dɪsks, wəd sɝɾənli hæv ətʃɹæktəd noʊɾəs əpɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, bʌt ɡɛɹɪθ hæd kənvɪnst əɹ ə ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ðiz mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ slɛndɝ lænsɪz ən ʃɔɹt hɔɹsboʊz. wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt, ðət smoʊk plum ɑn ðə fɑɹ bæŋk ɹoʊz fɹəm bɝnɪŋ wæɡənz əɹ səplaɪz. pɪnpɹɪks, jɛt ðoʊz pɪnpɹɪks keɪm ɛvɹi naɪt, səmtaɪmz wʌn, səmtaɪmz tu əɹ θɹi, tɪl ɛvɹiwʌn lʊk fəɹ smoʊk fɝs θɪŋ ɑn ɹaɪzɪŋ.

Two hundred light cavalry, in boiled leather breastplates or coats covered with metal discs, would certainly have attracted notice appearing on the riverbank, but Gareth had convinced her of the necessity of these men with their slender lances and short horsebows. Without any doubt, that smoke plume on the far bank rose from burning wagons or supplies. Pinpricks, yet those pinpricks came every night, sometimes one, sometimes two or three, till everyone looked for smoke first thing on rising.

hʌntɪŋ ðə ɹeɪɾɝz daʊn hæd pɹuvd ɪmpɑsəbəl, soʊ fɑɹ. sʌɾən snoʊ skwɔlz flɛɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə pɝsuɝz, əɹ fɪɹs fɹizɪŋ naɪt wɪnz, əɹ ðə tʃɹæks sɪmpli vænɪʃt əbɹʌpli, ðə snoʊ bɪɑn ðə læs hʊfpɹɪn əz smuð əz fɹɛʃ fɔlən. ðə ɹɛzəduz ʌv wivɪŋz meɪɾ ɪt pleɪn ɪnʌf ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ eɪɾəd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn teɪkɪŋ ə tʃæns ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd mɛn ən meɪbi sɪstɝz ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, tu. fju θɪŋz kəd pliz ɪleɪɾə mɔɹ ðən ɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ.

Hunting the raiders down had proved impossible, so far. Sudden snow squalls flared around the pursuers, or fierce freezing night winds, or the tracks simply vanished abruptly, the snow beyond the last hoofprint as smooth as fresh fallen. The residues of weavings made it plain enough they were being aided by Aes Sedai, and there was no point in taking a chance that Elaida had men and maybe sisters on this side of the river, too. Few things could please Elaida more than getting her hands on Egwene al'Vere.

ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əɹ hoʊl ɛskɔɹt, ʌv kɔɹs. bɪsaɪdz ʃɛɹiəm, hɝ kipɝ, ʃi hæd ɹɪɾən aʊt wɪð sɪks mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ðoʊz u hæd wɔɹɾɝz hæd bɹɔt ðɛm, soʊ bɪhaɪn ðə sɪstɝ eɪt mɛn weɪɾəd ɪn kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks ðət ɹɪpəld ɪn kwizimækɪŋ fæʃən wən ə bɹiz kɑɾ əm ən ʌðɝwaɪz meɪd pɑɹts ə ɹaɪɾɝz ən hɔɹsəz sim tə vænɪʃ ɪndə ðə tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋks. əwɛɹ ə ðə deɪnʒɝz - fɹəm ɹeɪɾɝz, ət list - əwɛɹ ðət ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ waʊn taɪt tə nɪɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ, ðeɪ wɑtʃt ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kɑps əz ðoʊ ðə kævəlɹimən wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. ðə seɪfti ʌv ðɛɹ oʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ðɛɹ pɹaɪmɛɹi kənsɝn, ən ðət ðeɪ tʃɹʌstɪd tə noʊ wʌn ɛls. sɑɹɪn, ə blæk-bɪɹɾəd stʌmp ʌv ə mæn, nɑt ðət ʃɔɹt bʌt vɛɹi waɪd, steɪd soʊ kloʊs tə naɪsaʊ ðəɾ i sim tə lum oʊvɝ ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv jɛloʊ, ən dʒɔɹi mænədʒ tə lum oʊvɝ mɔɹvɹɪn əz wɛl, ðoʊ hi wɑz æktʃəli  ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ʃi. əz bɹɔɾ əz sɑɹɪn, bʌt vɛɹi ʃɔɹɾ ivən fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn. maɪɹɛlz θɹi wɔɹɾɝz, ðə θɹi ʃi dɛɹɾ æknɑlɪdʒ, klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn əɹ əntɪl ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv muvd əɹ hɔɹs wɪθaʊt pʊʃɪŋ wʌn ə ðɛɹz aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ. æneɪjəz sɛɾɑɡænə, lin ən dɑɹk ən əz bjuɾəfəl əz ʃi wɑz pleɪn, ɔlmoʊs mænədʒ tə sɝaʊn əɹ baɪ hɪmsɛlf, ən tɝveɪl, wɪð ɪz boʊl noʊz ən skɑɹd feɪs, dɪd ðə seɪm wɪð bioʊnɪn. kɑɹlɪnjə hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝ, nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl fəɹ ə waɪt, bʌt ʃi stʌɾid ðə mɛn fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə hɝ fɝ-laɪn kaʊl əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹɪndɪŋ wʌn.

They were not her whole escort, of course. Besides Sheriam, her Keeper, she had ridden out with six more Aes Sedai this morning, and those who had Warders had brought them, so behind the sister eight men waited in color-shifting cloaks that rippled in queasymaking fashion when a breeze caught them and otherwise made parts of riders and horses seem to vanish into the tree trunks. Aware of the dangers - from raiders, at least - aware that their Aes Sedai were wound tight to near breaking, they watched the surrounding copse as though the cavalrymen were not there.
