The safety of their own Aes Sedai was their primary concern, and that they trusted to no one else. Sarin, a black-bearded stump of a man, not that short but very wide, stayed so close to Nisao that he seemed to loom over the diminutive Yellow, and Jori managed to loom over Morvrin as well, though he was actually shorter than she. As broad as Sarin, but very short even for a Cairhienin. Myrelle's three Warders, the three she dared acknowledge, clustered around her until she could not have moved her horse without pushing one of theirs out of her way. Anaiya's Setagana, lean and dark and as beautiful as she was plain, almost managed to surround her by himself, and Tervail, with his bold nose and scarred face, did the same with Beonin. Carlinya had no Warder, not unusual for a White, but she studied the men from the depths of her fur-lined cowl as if thinking about rinding one.

nɑt tu lɔŋ əɡoʊ, ɛɡwin wʊɾə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd tə bi sin wɪð ðoʊz sɪks wɪmən. ðeɪ ən ʃɛɹiəm hæɾ ɔl swɔɹn fiəlti tə hɝ, fəɹ vɛɹiəs ɹizənz, ən niðɝ ðeɪ nɔɹ ʃi wɑntəd ðə fæk noʊn əɹ ivən səspɛktəd. ðeɪ hæd bɪn əɹ weɪ tə ɪnfluəns ɪvɛns, tə ði ɪkstɛn ðət ʃi kʊd, wən ɛvɹiwʌn θɔɾ əɹ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə fɪɡjɝhɛd, ə ɡɝl æmɪɝlɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ kəd juz əz ɪt wɪʃt ən noʊ wʌn lɪsən tə. ðə hɔl hæd lɔs ðəɾ ɪluʒən wən ʃi bɹɔɾ əm tə dɪklɛɹ wɔɹ ɑn ɪleɪɾə, faɪnəli ædmɪɾɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn əbaʊt sɪns ðə deɪ ðeɪ hæd flɛd ðə taʊɝ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, bʌt ðəɾ oʊnli meɪd ðə hɔl, ən ði ədʒəz, wɝi oʊvɝ wʌt ʃi wəd də nɛkst ən tʃɹaɪ tə fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz mɛt wɪð ðɛɹ əpɹuvəl. ðə sɪɾɝz hæd bɪn vɛɹi sɝpɹaɪzd wən ʃi æksɛptɪd ðɛɹ sədʒɛstʃən ʌv ə kaʊnsəl, wʌn sɪstɝ fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ, tə ædvaɪz əɹ wɪð ðɛɹ wɪzdəm ən ɪkspɪɹiəns. əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ θɔɾ əɹ səksɛs wɪð ðə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ hæd ɡɔn tə hɝ hɛd. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi hæd dʒʌs toʊl mɔɹvɹɪn ən æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ ðə sɪstɝz tʃoʊzən, ən ðeɪ ɹɪteɪn ɪnʌf pɹɛstiʒ wɪðɪn ðɛɹ ədʒəz tə mænədʒ ɪt, dʒʌst. ʃi hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ tə ðɛɹ ædvaɪs, ɪf nɑɾ ɔlweɪz teɪkɪŋ ɪt, fəɹ wiks baɪ ðət taɪm, bʌt naʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛni nid tə ɝeɪnʒ fɝɾɪv miɾɪŋz əɹ pæs mɛsədʒəz ɪn sikɹət.

Not too long ago, Egwene would have hesitated to be seen with those six women. They and Sheriam had all sworn fealty to her, for various reasons, and neither they nor she wanted the fact known or even suspected. They had been her way to influence events, to the extent that she could, when everyone thought her no more than a figurehead, a girl Amyrlin the Hall of the Tower could use as it wished and no one listened to. The Hall had lost that illusion when she brought them to declare war on Elaida, finally admitting what they had been about since the day they had fled the Tower in the first place, but that only made the Hall, and the Ajahs, worry over what she would do next and try to figure out how to make sure that whatever it was met with their approval. The Sitters had been very surprised when she accepted their suggestion of a council, one sister from each Ajah, to advise her with their wisdom and experience. Or perhaps they thought her success with the declaration of war had gone to her head. Of course, she had just told Morvrin and Anaiya and the others to make sure they were the sisters chosen, and they retained enough prestige within their Ajahs to manage it, just. She had been listening to their advice, if not always taking it, for weeks by that time, but now there was no longer any need to arrange furtive meetings or pass messages in secret.

ɪt simd, haʊɛvɝ, ðət ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən ədɪʃən tə ðə pɑɹɾi waɪl ɛɡwin wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə taʊɝ.

It seemed, however, that there had been an addition to the party while Egwene was staring at the Tower.

ʃɛɹiəm, wɛɹɪŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ blu stoʊl ə hɝ ɔfəs aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ kloʊk, mænədʒd ə vɛɹi fɔɹməl baʊ fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl. ðə fleɪmhɛɹd wʊmən kəd bi ɪnkɹɛɾəbli fɔɹməl ət taɪmz. "mʌðɝ, ðə sɪɾɝ dɛlænə wɪʃɪz tə spik wɪð ju," ʃi sɛɾ əz ɪf ɛɡwin kəd nɑt si ðə staʊt ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ɑn ə dæpəl mɛɹ ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz ʃɛɹiəmz blæk-fʊɾɪd maʊnt. "ɑn ə mæɾɝ ə səm ɪmpɔɹɾəns, soʊ ʃi sɛz." ən ðə slaɪt tʌtʃ ʌv æspɹəɾi mɛn dɛlænə hæd nɑt toʊld əɹ wʌt mæɾɝ. ʃɛɹiəm wəd nɑɾ əv laɪk ðæt. ʃi kəd bi vɛɹi dʒɛləs ə hɝ pəzɪʃən. "ɪn pɹaɪvət, ɪf jə pliz, mʌðɝ," dɛlænə sɛd, pʊʃɪŋ bæk əɹ dɑɹk hʊd tə ɹɪvil hɛɹ nɪɹli ðə kʌlɝ ə sɪlvɝ. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz dip fəɹ ə wʊmənz, bʌɾ ɪt hɑɹdli kæɹid ði ɝdʒənsi ʌv sʌmwʌn wɪð ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz tə spik ʌv.

Sheriam, wearing the narrow blue stole of her office outside her cloak, managed a very formal bow from her saddle. The flamehaired woman could be incredibly formal at times. "Mother, the Sitter Delana wishes to speak with you," she said as if Egwene could not see the stout Gray sister sitting there on a dappled mare almost as dark as Sheriam's black-footed mount. "On a matter of some importance, so she says." And the slight touch of asperity meant Delana had not told her what matter. Sheriam would not have liked that. She could be very jealous of her position. "In private, if you please, Mother," Delana said, pushing back her dark hood to reveal hair nearly the color of silver. Her voice was deep for a woman's, but it hardly carried the urgency of someone with important matters to speak of.

hɝ pɹɛzəns wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə sɝpɹaɪz. dɛlænə ɔfən səpɔɹɾəd ɛɡwin ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, wən sɪɾɝz wɝ kwɪbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ wɛðɝ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ dɪsɪʒən æktʃəli  kənsɝn ðə wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə. ðət mɛn ðə hɔl wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə səpɔɹɾ ɛɡwinz kəmænz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd stʊd wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs, ən ivən ðə sɪɾɝz u hæd stʊd fəɹ wɔɹ dɪd nɑt hæf laɪk ðət lɪɾəl fækt, wɪtʃ meɪd fəɹ ɛnləs kwɪbəlɪŋ. ðeɪ wɑntəd tə pʊl ɪleɪɾə daʊn, jɛt lɛf tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə wʊɾə əv dʌn nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɑɹɡju. tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, ðoʊ, dɛlænəz səpɔɹt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz wɛlkəm.

Her presence was something of a surprise. Delana often supported Egwene in the Hall of the Tower, when Sitters were quibbling over whether a particular decision actually concerned the war against Elaida. That meant the Hall was required to support Egwene's commands as if they had stood with the greater consensus, and even the Sitters who had stood for war did not half like that little fact, which made for endless quibbling. They wanted to pull Elaida down, yet left to themselves, the Hall would have done nothing but argue. Truth to tell, though, Delana's support was not always welcome.

wʌn deɪ ʃi kəd bi ðə vɛɹi ɪmədʒ ʌv ə ɡɹeɪ nəɡoʊʃieɪɾɝ sikɪŋ kənsɛnsəs, ən ðə nɛkst soʊ stʃɹaɪɾənt ɪn əɹ ɑɹɡjəməns ðəɾ ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ wɪðɪn hɪɹɪŋ ɡɑɾ əɹ bæk ʌp. ʃi hæd bɪn noʊn tə sɛt ðə kæɾ əmʌŋ ðə pɪdʒənz ɪn ʌðɝ weɪz, tu. noʊ fjuɝ ðən θɹi taɪmz naʊ, ʃi hæd dɪmændəd ðə hɔl meɪk ə fɔɹməl dɛklɝeɪʃən ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz blæk ədʒɑ, wɪtʃ ɪnɛvəɾəbli lɛd tə ən ɑkwɝd saɪləns əntɪl sʌmwʌn kɔl fəɹ ðə sɪɾɪŋ tə bi ədʒɝnd. fju wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə dɪskʌs ðə blæk ədʒɑ oʊpənli.

One day she could be the very image of a Gray negotiator seeking consensus, and the next so strident in her arguments that every Sitter within hearing got her back up. She had been known to set the cat among the pigeons in other ways, too. No fewer than three times now, she had demanded the Hall make a formal declaration that Elaida was Black Ajah, which inevitably led to an awkward silence until someone called for the sitting to be adjourned. Few were willing to discuss the Black Ajah openly.

dɛlænə wəd dɪskʌs ɛniθɪŋ, fɹəm haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə faɪn pɹɑpɝ kloʊðz fəɹ naɪn hʌnʒɹəd ən eɪɾi-sɛvən nɑvəsɪz tə wɛðɝ ɪleɪɾə hæd sikɹət səpɔɹɾɝz əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz, ənʌðɝ tɑpɪk ðət ɡeɪv moʊst sɪstɝz ə keɪs ə ðə pɹɪkəlz. wɪtʃ lɛf ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv waɪ ʃi hæd ɹɪɾən aʊt soʊ ɝli, ən baɪ hɝsɛlf.

Delana would discuss anything, from how they were to find proper clothes for nine hundred and eighty-seven novices to whether Elaida had secret supporters among the sisters, another topic that gave most sisters a case of the prickles. Which left the question of why she had ridden out so early, and by herself.

ʃi hæd nɛvɝ əpɹoʊtʃt ɛɡwin bɪfɔɹ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ sɪɾɝ əɹ θɹi fəɹ kʌmpəni. dɛlænəz peɪl blu aɪz ɡeɪv əweɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðən dɪɾ əɹ smuð ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs.

She had never approached Egwene before without another Sitter or three for company. Delana's pale blue eyes gave away no more than did her smooth Aes Sedai face.

"waɪl wi ɹaɪd," ɛɡwin toʊl hɝ. "wi wɪl wɑn ə lɪɾəl pɹaɪvəsi," ʃi æɾəd wən ʃɛɹiəm oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "steɪ bæk wɪð ði ʌðɝz, pliz." ðə kipɝz ɡɹin aɪz taɪɾənd ɪn wʌt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪn æŋɡɝ. ən ɪfɪʃən kipɝ, ən iɡɝ wɪð ɪt, ʃi hæd pɪn əɹ hoʊps ɑn ɛɡwin ən meɪd lɪɾəl sikɹət ðət ʃi dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ɪkskluɾəd fɹəm ɛni miɾɪŋ ɛɡwin hæd. əpsɛɾ əɹ nɑt, ʃi baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn æksɛptəns wɪð oʊnli ə smɔl hɛzəteɪʃən. ʃɛɹiəm hæd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn wɪtʃ ə ðɛm kəmændəd, bʌt ʃi dɪd naʊ.

"While we ride," Egwene told her. "We will want a little privacy," she added when Sheriam opened her mouth. "Stay back with the others, please." The Keeper's green eyes tightened in what might almost have been anger. An efficient Keeper, and eager with it, she had pinned her hopes on Egwene and made little secret that she disliked being excluded from any meeting Egwene had. Upset or not, she bowed her head in acceptance with only a small hesitation. Sheriam had not always known which of them commanded, but she did now.

ðə læn tɛndəɾ ʌpwɝd fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn, nɑɾ ɪn hɪlz bʌt sɪmpli ɹaɪzɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə mɑnstʃɹəs pik ðət lum tə ðə wɛst, soʊ mæsɪv ɪt sim tə mɑk ðə neɪm maʊntən.

The land tended upward from the River Erinin, not in hills but simply rising toward the monstrous peak that loomed to the west, so massive it seemed to mock the name mountain.

dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt wʊɾə taʊɝɾ əbʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ivən ɪn ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld; ɪn ðə ɹɛləɾɪvli flæt kʌntʃɹi ɝaʊn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪts waɪtkæp kɹɛst sim tə ɹitʃ ðə hɛvənz, ɪspɛʃli wən ə θɪn θɹɛɾ ə smoʊk wɑz stʃɹimɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dʒæɡd tɑp əz ɪt wɑz naʊ. ə θɪn θɹɛɾ ət ðət haɪt wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɪntaɪɝli, kloʊs ət hænd. tʃɹiz ɡeɪv aʊt lɛs ðən hæfweɪ ʌp dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, ən noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ səksiɾəd ɪn ɹitʃɪŋ ðə kɹɛst əɹ ivən kʌmɪŋ kloʊs, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz sɛd ðə sloʊps wɝ lɪɾɝd wɪð ðə boʊnz ə ðoʊz u hæd tʃɹaɪd. waɪ ɛniwʌn wəd tʃɹaɪ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, noʊ wʌn kəd kwaɪɾ ɪkspleɪn. səmtaɪmz ðə lɔŋ ivnɪŋ ʃædoʊ ʌv ðə maʊntən stʃɹɛtʃt ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɪɾi. pipəl u lɪvd ɪn ðə ɹidʒən wɝ əkʌstəm tə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn dɑməneɪɾɪŋ ðə skaɪ, mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ wɝ əkʌstəm tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ lumɪŋ əbʌv ðə sɪɾi wɔlz ən vɪzəbəl fəɹ maɪlz.

Dragonmount would have towered above everything else even in the Spine of the World; in the relatively flat country around Tar Valon, its whitecapped crest seemed to reach the heavens, especially when a thin thread of smoke was streaming away from the jagged top as it was now. A thin thread at that height would be something else entirely, close at hand. Trees gave out less than halfway up Dragonmount, and no one had ever succeeded in reaching the crest or even coming close, though it was said the slopes were littered with the bones of those who had tried. Why anyone would try in the first place, no one could quite explain. Sometimes the long evening shadow of the mountain stretched all the way to the city. People who lived in the region were accustomed to Dragonmount dominating the sky, much as they were accustomed to the White Tower looming above the city walls and visible for miles.

boʊθ wɝ əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ fɪkstʃɝz ðət hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðəɹ ən ɔlweɪz wəd bi, bʌt kɹɑps ən kɹæfs ɑkjəpaɪd ðə pipəlz laɪvz, nɑt maʊntənz əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Both were unchanging fixtures that had always been there and always would be, but crops and crafts occupied the people's lives, not mountains or Aes Sedai.

ɪn taɪni hæmləts ɔfən əɹ ə dʌzən stoʊn haʊsəz ɹuft ɪn θætʃ əɹ sleɪt, ən ði əkeɪʒənəl vɪlədʒ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd, tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ əɹ kæɹiɪŋ bʌkəts ʌv wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə wɛlz stɑp tə ɡeɪp ət ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə dɝt tʃɹæks ðət pæs fəɹ ɹoʊdz wən nɑt kʌvɝɾ ɪn snoʊ. ðeɪ kæɹid noʊ bænɝz, bʌɾ ə fju ʌv ðə soʊlʒɝz wɔɹ ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɝkt ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks əɹ koʊtslivz, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝz' stʃɹeɪnʒ kloʊks neɪmd ət list səm ə ðə wɪmən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ivən ðɪs nɪɹ ðə sɪɾi, sɪstɝz hæd bɪn ən ənkɑmən saɪt tɪl ɹisənli, ən ðeɪ wɝ stɪl sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk ə tʃaɪlz aɪz ɡlim. bʌt ðɛn, ðə soʊlʒɝz ðɛmsɛlvz pɹɑbli keɪm kloʊs ɪn ðə lɪst ə mɑɹvəlz. ðə fɑɹmz ðət fɛd tɑɹ vəlɑn kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə lænd, stoʊn-wɔl filz sɝaʊndɪŋ spɹɔlɪŋ haʊsəz ən tɔl bɑɹnz ə stoʊn əɹ bɹɪk, wɪð kɑpsɪz ən kɑpɪsɪz ən θɪkəts ə tʃɹiz bɪtwin, ən ɡɹups ə fɑɹm tʃɪlʒɹən ɔfən ɹæn ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə laɪn ə tʃɹævəl, lipɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ laɪk hɛɹz. wɪntɝ tʃɔɹz kɛp moʊst oʊldɝ foʊk ɪndɔɹz, bʌt ðoʊz u vɛntʃɝɾ aʊt, hɛvəli bʌndəld əɡɛns ðə koʊld, spɛɹd bɛɹli ə ɡlæns fəɹ soʊlʒɝz əɹ wɔɹɾɝz əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. spɹɪŋ wəd bi kʌmɪŋ sun, ən ðə plaʊɪŋ ən plæntɪŋ, ən wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd wəd nɑɾ əfɛk ðæt. ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, ɪt wəd nɑt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn tə ɡɑɹdz ənlɛs ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ən ətæk, ən lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ə stʃɹɔŋ pɑɹɾi ʌv fɔɹ-ɹaɪɾɝz ən laɪnz ə flæŋkɝz, wɪð tʃɹeɪlɝz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɹɪɹ waɪl i lɛd ðə mæs ə ðə soʊlʒɝz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ðə wɔɹɾɝz u fɑloʊd kloʊsli ɑn ðə hilz ə ʃɛɹiəm ən ðə "kaʊnsəl." ðeɪ ɔl meɪɾ ə lɑɹdʒ, lɑpsaɪɾɪd ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛɡwin, ən ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmædʒən ʃi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪɾ əloʊn wɪð dɛlænə ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ɝaʊn tu kloʊsli. əɹ ɪf ʃi lʊk bɪɑnd. ɪnstɛɾ ə pɹɛsɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪɾɝ tə spik - ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ ɹaɪd bæk tə kæmp, ən noʊ wʌn wɑz əlaʊd tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ wɛɹ ðə wiv maɪt bi əbzɝvd; ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv taɪm tə hɪɹ wʌt dɛlænə hæd tə seɪ -  ɛɡwin kəmpɛɹd ðə fɑɹmz ðeɪ pæs tə ðoʊz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. pɝhæps ðə ɹiləzeɪʃən ðət ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hoʊm meɪɾ əɹ stʌɾi ðɛm. æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ kəd nɛvɝ bi ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl, jɛt ʃi niɾəd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. jə kəd fɝɡɛɾ u jə wɝ ɪf jə fɝɡɑt wɛɹ jə keɪm fɹʌm, ən səmtaɪmz ði ɪnkipɝz dɔɾɝ fɹəm ɛmənz fil simd ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ tə hɝ. ɛni ʌv ðiz fɑɹmz wʊɾə lʊk dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd, sɛt daʊn nɪɹ ɛmənz fild, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑt pʊɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ɑn waɪ, ɪɡzækli. ə dɪfɹənt ʃeɪp tə ðə haʊsəz, ə dɪfɹən slæn tə ðə ɹufs. ən mɔɹ ɔfən sleɪt tɑpt ə haʊs ðən θætʃ, hɪɹ, wən jə kəd meɪk aʊɾ iðɝ θɹu ðə snoʊ ðət wɑz ɔfən maʊndɪɾ ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz lɛs θætʃ ən mɔɹ stoʊn ən bɹɪk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz naʊ ðən ðəɹ hæd bɪn. ʃi hæd sin ɪt, ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. tʃeɪnʒ keɪm soʊ sloʊli jə nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ɪt kɹipɪŋ ʌp ɑn ju, əɹ fɑɹ tu fæs fəɹ kʌmfɝt, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm. nʌθɪŋ steɪd ðə seɪm, ivən wən jə θɔɾ ɪt dɪd. əɹ hoʊpt ɪt wʊd.

In tiny hamlets often or a dozen stone houses roofed in thatch or slate, and the occasional village of a hundred, children playing in the snow or carrying buckets of water from the wells stopped to gape at the soldiers riding along the dirt tracks that passed for roads when not covered in snow. They carried no banners, but a few of the soldiers wore the Flame of Tar Valon worked on their cloaks or coatsleeves, and the Warders' strange cloaks named at least some of the women as Aes Sedai. Even this near the city, sisters had been an uncommon sight till recently, and they were still something to make a child's eyes gleam. But then, the soldiers themselves probably came close in the list of marvels. The farms that fed Tar Valon covered most of the land, stone-walled fields surrounding sprawling houses and tall barns of stone or brick, with copses and coppices and thickets of trees between, and groups of farm children often ran a little distance parallel to the line of travel, leaping across the snow like hares. Winter chores kept most older folk indoors, but those who ventured out, heavily bundled against the cold, spared barely a glance for soldiers or Warders or Aes Sedai. Spring would be coming soon, and the plowing and planting, and what Aes Sedai did would not affect that. The Light willing, it would not. There was no point to guards unless they rode as if expecting an attack, and Lord Gareth had arranged a strong party of fore-riders and lines of flankers, with trailers riding to the rear while he led the mass of the soldiers right behind the Warders who followed closely on the heels of Sheriam and the "council." They all made a large, lopsided ring around Egwene, and she could almost imagine she was riding through the countryside alone with Delana if she did not look around too closely. Or if she looked beyond. Instead of pressing the Gray Sitter to speak - it was a long ride back to camp, and no one was allowed to weave a gateway where the weave might be observed; there was plenty of time to hear what Delana had to say -  Egwene compared the farms they passed to those in the Two Rivers. Perhaps the realization that the Two Rivers was no longer home made her study them. Acknowledging the truth could never be a betrayal, yet she needed to remember the Two Rivers. You could forget who you were if you forgot where you came from, and sometimes the innkeeper's daughter from Emond's Field seemed a stranger to her. Any of these farms would have looked decidedly odd, set down near Emond's Field, though she could not put a finger on why, exactly. A different shape to the houses, a different slant to the roofs. And more often slate topped a house than thatch, here, when you could make out either through the snow that was often mounded on the rooftops. Of course, there was less thatch and more stone and brick in the Two Rivers now than there had been. She had seen it, in Tel'aran'rhiod. Change came so slowly you never noticed it creeping up on you, or far too fast for comfort, but it came. Nothing stayed the same, even when you thought it did. Or hoped it would.

"sʌm θɪŋk jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə bɑn ɪm jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ," dɛlænə sɛd sʌɾənli ɪn ə kwaɪət vɔɪs. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɛnɡeɪdʒɪŋ ɪn kæʒəwəl kɑnvɝseɪʃən. hɝ hoʊl ətɛnʃən sim tə bi ɑn ɝeɪnʒɪŋ ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk wɪð ɡɹin-ɡlʌv hænz. ʃi ɹoʊd wɛl, blɛndɪŋ wɪð ðə moʊʃən ə hɝ mɛɹ soʊ ɛfɝtləsli ðət ʃi əpɪɹɾ ʌnəwɛɹ ə ði ænəməl. "sʌm θɪŋk pɝhæps jə ɔlɹɛɾi hæv. aɪ hævən hæd wʌn maɪsɛlf fəɹ səm taɪm, bʌt dʒʌs noʊɪŋ jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ ɪz ðəɹ kən bi ə kʌmfɝt. ɪf jə tʃuz ðə ɹaɪt wʌn." ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ - ʃi wɑz pɹaʊd ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡeɪp ət ðə wʊmən; ðɪs wɑz ðə vɛɹi læs tɑpɪk ʃi wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd - ən dɛlænə æɾəd, "lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ. hi spɛnz ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə taɪm wɪð ju. hiz ɹæðɝ oʊldɝ ðən ɪz juʒəwəl, bʌt ɡɹinz ɔfən tʃuz ə mɔɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns mæn fəɹ ðɛɹ fɝst. aɪ noʊ jə nɛvɝ æktʃəli  hæɾ ən ədʒɑ, jɛɾ aɪ ɔfən θɪŋk ə jə əz ə ɡɹin. aɪ wʌndɝ, wɪl sɪuən bi ɹɪlivd ɪf jə bɑn hɪm, əɹ ʌpsɛt? səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk wʌn, səmtaɪmz ði ʌðɝ. ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp, ɪf ɪt kən bi kɔl ðæt, ɪz moʊs pəkjuljɝ, jɛt ʃi simz kəmplitli ʌnɪmbɛɹəst." "ju mʌst æsk sɪuən hɝsɛlf əbaʊt ðæt." ɛɡwinz smaɪl hæd səm baɪɾ ɪn ɪt. soʊ dɪɾ əɹ toʊn, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʌndɝstæn hɝsɛlf waɪ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæɾ ɔfɝɾ əɹ ɪz lɔɪəlti, bʌt ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ hæd bɛɾɝ jusəz fəɹ ɪts taɪm ðən ɡɑsəpɪŋ laɪk vɪlədʒ wɪmən. "ju kən tɛl huɛvɝ jə tʃuz ðəɾ aɪv bɑndəd noʊ wʌn, dɛlænə. lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ spɛnz taɪm wɪð mi, əz jə pʊɾ ɪt, aɪm æm ði æmɪɝlɪn hiz ɪz maɪ dʒɛnɝəl. jə meɪ ɹimaɪn əm ə ðæt, əz wɛl." soʊ dɛlænə θɔɾ ə hɝ əz ə ɡɹin. ðət wɑz ði ədʒɑ ʃi wəɾ əv tʃoʊzən, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi wɑntəɾ oʊnli wʌn wɔɹɾɝ. bʌt ɡɔɪn wɑz iðɝ ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn əɹ ɛls ɑn ɪz weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən iðɝ weɪ, ʃi wəd nɑt leɪ hænz ɑn ɪm sun.

"Some think you're going to bond him your Warder," Delana said suddenly in a quiet voice. She might have been engaging in casual conversation. Her whole attention seemed to be on arranging the hood of her cloak with green-gloved hands. She rode well, blending with the motion of her mare so effortlessly that she appeared unaware of the animal. "Some think perhaps you already have. I haven't had one myself for some time, but just knowing your Warder is there can be a comfort. If you choose the right one." Egwene raised an eyebrow - she was proud that she did not gape at the woman; this was the very last topic she would have expected - and Delana added, "Lord Gareth. He spends a great deal of time with you. He's rather older than is usual, but Greens often choose a more experienced man for their first. I know you never actually had an Ajah, yet I often think of you as a Green. I wonder, will Siuan be relieved if you bond him, or upset? Sometimes I think one, sometimes the other. Their relationship, if it can be called that, is most peculiar, yet she seems completely unembarrassed." "You must ask Siuan herself about that." Egwene's smile had some bite in it. So did her tone, for that matter. She did not entirely understand herself why Gareth Bryne had offered her his loyalty, but the Hall of the Tower had better uses for its time than gossiping like village women. "You can tell whoever you choose that I've bonded no one, Delana. Lord Gareth spends time with me, as you put it, because I am the Amyrlin and he is my general. You may remind them of that, as well." So Delana thought of her as a Green. That was the Ajah she would have chosen, though in truth, she wanted only one Warder. But Gawyn was either inside Tar Valon or else on his way to Caemlyn, and either way, she would not lay hands on him soon.

ʃi pæɾəd deɪʃɝz nɛk ənnɛsəsɛɹəli ən tʃɹaɪd tə kip əɹ smaɪl fɹəm bɪkʌmɪŋ ə ɡlɛɹ. ɪt hæd bɪn plɛzən tə fɝɡɛt ðə hɔl, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, fəɹ ə waɪl. ðə hɔl meɪɾ əɹ ʌndɝstænd waɪ sɪuən hæd soʊ ɔfən lʊk laɪk ə bɛɹ wɪð ə sɔɹ tuθ wən ʃi wɑz æmɪɝlɪn.

She patted Daishar's neck unnecessarily and tried to keep her smile from becoming a glare. It had been pleasant to forget the Hall, among other things, for a while. The Hall made her understand why Siuan had so often looked like a bear with a sore tooth when she was Amyrlin.

"aɪ wʊdn seɪ ɪts bɪkʌm ə mæɾɝ fəɹ waɪd dɪskʌʃən," dɛlænə mɝmɝd. "soʊ fɑɹ. stɪl, ðəɹ ɪz səm ɪntʃɹəst ɪn wɛðɝ jəl bɑn ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən hu. aɪ daʊt ðət ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn wəd bi kənsɪɾɝd ə waɪz pɪk." ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə lʊk bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ət lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ, ɛɡwin θɔt, bʌt wən ðə sɪɾɝ tɝn bæk ɝaʊnd, ʃi sɛd, vɛɹi sɔfli, "ʃɛɹiəm wɑz nɛvɝ jəɹ tʃɔɪs fəɹ kipɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt jə mʌs noʊ ðət ði ədʒəz sɛt ðə ɹɛst ə ðət lɑt tə wɑtʃ ju, əz wɛl." hɝ dæpəld ɡɹeɪ mɛɹ wɑz ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən deɪʃɝ, soʊ ʃi hæd tə lʊk ʌp əɾ ɛɡwin, wɪtʃ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə də wɪθaʊt simɪŋ tə. ðoʊz wɔɾɝi blu aɪz wɝ sʌɾənli kwaɪt ʃɑɹp. "ðɛɹ wɑz səm θɔt ðət sɪuən maɪt bi ædvaɪzɪŋ jə . . . tu wɛl . . . æftɝ ðə weɪ jə bɹɔɾ əbaʊt ðə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə. bʌt ʃiz stɪl ɹɪzɛnfəl oʊvɝ əɹ tʃeɪnʒd sɝkəmstænsəz, ɪzənt ʃi? ʃɛɹiəm ɪz sin əz ðə moʊs laɪkli kʌlpɹɪt, naʊ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ði ədʒəz wɑn ə lɪɾəl wɔɹnɪŋ ɪf jə dɪsaɪd tə pʊl ənʌðɝ sɝpɹaɪz." "aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ðə wɔɹnɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd pəlaɪtli. kʌlpɹɪt? ʃi hæd pɹuvən tə ðə hɔl ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi ðɛɹ pʌpət, jɛt moʊst ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi hæd tə bi sʌmwʌnz. ət lis noʊ wʌn səspɛktəd ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊɾ əɹ kaʊnsəl. ɪt wɑz tə bi hoʊp noʊ wʌn dɪd.

"I wouldn't say it has become a matter for wide discussion," Delana murmured. "So far. Still, there is some interest in whether you will bond a Warder, and who. I doubt that Gareth Bryne would be considered a wise pick." She twisted in her saddle to look behind them. At Lord Gareth, Egwene thought, but when the Sitter turned back around, she said, very softly, "Sheriam was never your choice for Keeper, of course, but you must know that the Ajahs set the rest of that lot to watch you, as well." Her dappled gray mare was shorter than Daishar, so she had to look up at Egwene, which she tried to do without seeming to. Those watery blue eyes were suddenly quite sharp. "There was some thought that Siuan might be advising you . . . too well . . . after the way you brought about the declaration of war against Elaida. But she's still resentful over her changed circumstances, isn't she? Sheriam is seen as the most likely culprit, now. In any case, the Ajahs want a little warning if you decide to pull another surprise." "I thank you for the warning," Egwene said politely. Culprit? She had proven to the Hall that she would not be their puppet, yet most insisted on thinking she had to be someone's. At least no one suspected the truth about her council. It was to be hoped no one did.

"ðɛɹ ɪz ənʌðɝ ɹizən jə ʃəd bi wɛɹi," dɛlænə wɛn ɑn, ði ɪntɛnsəɾi ɪn əɹ aɪz bɪlaɪɪŋ ðə kæʒəɑlnəs ə hɝ vɔɪs. ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ ðən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɛɡwin tə noʊ. "ju meɪ bi ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛni ædvaɪs wʌn ə ðɛm ɡɪvz jə kʌmz stʃɹeɪt fɹəm ðə hɛɾ ə hɝ ədʒɑ, ən əz jə noʊ, ðə hɛɾ ʌv ən ədʒɑ ən ɪts sɪɾɝz doʊn ɔlweɪz si aɪ tə aɪ. lɪsnɪŋ tu kloʊsli kəd pʊt jə əɾ ɑdz wɪð ðə hɔl. nɑɾ ɛvɹi dɪsɪʒən kənsɝnz ðə wɔɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌt jəl ʃʊɹli wɑn səm ə ðoʊz tə ɡoʊ jəɹ weɪ." "æn æmɪɝlɪn ʃəd lɪsən tə ɛvɹi saɪd bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ɛni dɪsɪʒən," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd, "bʌɾ əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ wɔɹnɪŋ wən ðeɪ ædvaɪz mi, dɔɾɝ." dɪd dɛlænə θɪŋk ʃi wɑz ə ful? əɹ pɝhæps ðə wʊmən wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ æŋɡɹi. æŋɡɝ meɪd fəɹ heɪsti dɪsɪʒənz ən ɹæʃ wɝdz ðət səmtaɪmz wɝ hɑɹd tə teɪk bæk. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt dɛlænə wɑz eɪmɪŋ æt, bʌt wən sɪɾɝz kəd nɑt mənɪpjəleɪɾ əɹ wʌn weɪ, ðeɪ tʃɹaɪɾ ənʌðɝ. ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə pɹæktəs ɪn saɪdstɛpɪŋ mənɪpjəleɪʃən sɪns biɪŋ ɹeɪzd æmɪɝlɪn. teɪkɪŋ dip, ɹɛɡjəlɝ bɹɛθs, ʃi sɔt ðə bæləns ə kɑm ən faʊn ɪt. ʃi hæɾ ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ pɹæktəs ət ðæt, tu, ʌv leɪt.

"There is another reason you should be wary," Delana went on, the intensity in her eyes belying the casualness of her voice. This was more important to her than she wanted Egwene to know. "You may be sure that any advice one of them gives you comes straight from the head of her Ajah, and as you know, the head of an Ajah and its Sitters don't always see eye to eye. Listening too closely could put you at odds with the Hall. Not every decision concerns the war, remember, but you will surely want some of those to go your way." "An Amyrlin should listen to every side before making any decision," Egwene replied, "but I'll remember your warning when they advise me, Daughter." Did Delana think she was a fool? Or perhaps the woman was trying to make her angry. Anger made for hasty decisions and rash words that sometimes were hard to take back. She could not imagine what Delana was aiming at, but when Sitters could not manipulate her one way, they tried another. She had gotten a great deal of practice in sidestepping manipulation since being raised Amyrlin. Taking deep, regular breaths, she sought the balance of calm and found it. She had entirely too much practice at that, too, of late.

ðə ɡɹeɪ lʊkt ʌp əɾ əɹ pæs ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ hʊd, hɝ feɪs ʌɾɝli smuð. bʌɾ əɹ peɪl blu aɪz wɝ vɛɹi ʃɑɹp, naʊ, laɪk ɔɡɝz. "ju maɪɾ ɪnkwaɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ θɪŋk ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪð ɪleɪɾə, mʌðɝ."

The Gray looked up at her past the edge of her hood, her face utterly smooth. But her pale blue eyes were very sharp, now, like augers. "You might inquire what they think on the subject of negotiations with Elaida, Mother."

ɛɡwin ɔlmoʊst smaɪld. ðə pɔz hæd bɪn vɛɹi dɪlɪbɝɪt. əpɛɹənli dɛlænə dɪslaɪk biɪŋ kɔl dɔɾɝ baɪ ə wʊmən jʌŋɡɝ ðən moʊs nɑvəsɪz. jʌŋɡɝ ðən moʊst u hæd kʌm fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, lɛɾ əloʊn ðə nuəst. bʌt ðɛn, dɛlænə hɝsɛlf wɑz tu jʌŋ tə bi ə sɪɾɝ. ən ʃi kəd nɑt hoʊld əɹ tɛmpɝ əz wɛl əz ði ɪnkipɝz dɔɾɝ. "ænd waɪ wəɾ aɪ æsk ðæt?" "bɪkɔz ðə sʌbʒɪkt əz kʌm ʌp ɪn ðə hɔl ɪn ðə læs fju deɪz. nɑɾ əz ə pɹəpoʊzəl, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn mɛnʃənd, vɛɹi kwaɪətli, baɪ vɛɹɪlɪn, ən baɪ tɑkimə, ən ɔlsoʊ baɪ mæɡlə. ən feɪsɛl ən sɛɝɔɪjə hæv əpɪɹɾ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌt ðeɪv hæd tə seɪ." kɑm əɹ noʊ kɑm, ə wɝm ʌv æŋɡɝ sʌɾənli ɹɪθd ɪnsaɪɾ ɛɡwin, ən kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪt wɑz noʊ izi tæsk. ðoʊz faɪv hæd bɪn sɪɾɝz bɪfɔɹ ðə taʊɝ wɑz bɹoʊkən, bʌt mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, ðeɪ wɝ dɪvaɪɾəd bɪtwin ðə tu meɪdʒɝ fækʃənz stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə hɔl. ɪn ɹiæləɾi, ðeɪ wɝ dɪvaɪɾəd bɪtwin fɑloʊɪŋ ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn, jɛt ðət pɛɹ wəɾ əpoʊz wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪf ɪt mɛn ðeɪ boʊθ dʒɹaʊnd. ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ kɛpt ən aɪɝn ɡɹɪp ɑn ðɛɹ fɑloʊɝz. ʃi maɪt bɪliv ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn pænɪk baɪ ɪvɛns, bʌt nɑt ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn. fəɹ hæf ə wik naʊ, tɔk ʌv ɪleɪɾə əɹ ɹəteɪkɪŋ ðə taʊɝ hæd bɪn ɔl bʌɾ oʊvɝwɛlm baɪ wɝid kɑnvɝseɪʃənz oʊvɝ ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbli paʊɝfəl, ɪmpɑsəbli lɔŋ ɪɹʌpʃən ə ðə paʊɝ. nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn wɑntəd tə noʊ wʌt hæd kɑzd ɪt, ən nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz əfɹeɪd tə lɝn. oʊnli jɛstɝdeɪ hæɾ ɛɡwin bɪn eɪbəl tə kənvɪns ðə hɔl ðəɾ ɪt mʌs bi seɪf fəɹ ə smɔl pɑɹɾi tə tʃɹævəl tə wɛɹ ðəɾ ɪɹʌpʃən hæd bɪn - ivən ðə mɛmɹi wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə pɪnpɔɪn ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn - ən moʊst sɪstɝz stɪl sim tə bi hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ kəlɛktɪv bɹɛθ əntɪl ækæɹən ən ði ʌðɝz ɹɪtɝnd. ɛvɹi ədʒɑ hæd wɑntəɾ ə ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪv, bʌɾ ækæɹən hæd bɪn ði oʊnli ɛɛs sədaɪ tə pʊʃ fɔɹwɝd.

Egwene almost smiled. The pause had been very deliberate. Apparently Delana disliked being called Daughter by a woman younger than most novices. Younger than most who had come from the Tower, let alone the newest. But then, Delana herself was too young to be a Sitter. And she could not hold her temper as well as the innkeeper's daughter. "And why would I ask that?" "Because the subject has come up in the Hall in the last few days. Not as a proposal, but it has been mentioned, very quietly, by Varilin, and by Takima, and also by Magla. And Faiselle and Saroiya have appeared interested in what they have had to say." Calm or no calm, a worm of anger suddenly writhed inside Egwene, and crushing it was no easy task. Those five had been Sitters before the Tower was broken, but more importantly, they were divided between the two major factions struggling for control of the Hall. In reality, they were divided between following Romanda or Lelaine, yet that pair would oppose one another if it meant they both drowned. They also kept an iron grip on their followers. She might believe the others had been panicked by events, but not Romanda or Lelaine. For half a week now, talk of Elaida or retaking the Tower had been all but overwhelmed by worried conversations over that impossibly powerful, impossibly long eruption of the Power. Nearly everyone wanted to know what had caused it, and nearly everyone was afraid to learn. Only yesterday had Egwene been able to convince the Hall that it must be safe for a small party to Travel to where that eruption had been - even the memory was strong enough for everyone to pinpoint exactly where it had been - and most sisters still seemed to be holding their collective breath until Akarrin and the others returned. Every Ajah had wanted a representative, but Akarrin had been the only Aes Sedai to push forward.

niðɝ ləleɪn nɔɹ ɹoʊmændə sim kənsɝnd, haʊɛvɝ. vaɪələn ən pɹəlɔŋd əz ðə dɪspleɪ hæd bɪn, ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ hæd bɪn vɛɹi fɑɹ əweɪ, ən noʊ hɑɹm dʌn ðət ðeɪ kəd si; ɪf ɪt wɑz ðə fɔɹseɪkənz wɝk, əz sim sɝɾən, ðə tʃæns ə lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ wɑz vænɪʃɪŋli smɔl, ən ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ðeɪ kəd də ɛniθɪŋ tə kaʊntɝ ɪɾ ivən smɔlɝ. weɪstɪŋ taɪm ən ɛfɝɾ ɑn ɪmpɑsəbɪləɾiz wɑz sɛnsləs wən ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsk leɪ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. soʊ ðeɪ sɛd, ɡɹɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tiθ oʊvɝ faɪndɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn əɡɹimənt. ðeɪ dɪɾ əɡɹi ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə mʌs bi stʃɹɪpt ə ðə stoʊl ən stæf, ðoʊ, ɹoʊmændə wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ fɝvɝ əz ləleɪn, ən ɪf ɪleɪɾə ənsiɾɪŋ ə fɔɹmɝ blu əz æmɪɝlɪn hæɾ ɛnɹeɪdʒ ləleɪn, ɪleɪɾəz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən ðət ðə blu ədʒɑ wɑz dɪsbændɪd hæd meɪɾ əɹ nɪɹ-ɹæbɪd. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əlaʊɪŋ tɔk ə nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən. . . . ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns.

Neither Lelaine nor Romanda seemed concerned, however. Violent and prolonged as the display had been, it also had been very far away, and no harm done that they could see; if it was the Forsaken's work, as seemed certain, the chance of learning anything was vanishingly small, and the possibility that they could do anything to counter it even smaller. Wasting time and effort on impossibilities was senseless when an important task lay right in front of them. So they said, gritting their teeth over finding themselves in agreement. They did agree that Elaida must be stripped of the stole and staff, though, Romanda with almost as much fervor as Lelaine, and if Elaida unseating a former Blue as Amyrlin had enraged Lelaine, Elaida's proclamation that the Blue Ajah was disbanded had made her near-rabid. If they were allowing talk of negotiation. . . . It made no sense.

ðə læs θɪŋ ɛɡwin wɑntəd wɑz fəɹ dɛlænə əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls tə səspɛk ðət ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ mɔɹ ðən ə sɛɾ ə ʃipdɔɡz sɛt tə wɑtʃ hɝ, bʌt ʃi sʌmən əm wɪð ə ʃɑɹp kɔl.

The last thing Egwene wanted was for Delana or anyone else to suspect that Sheriam and the others were more than a set of sheepdogs set to watch her, but she summoned them with a sharp call.

ðeɪ wɝ smɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə kip ðə sikɹəts ðət niɾəd kipɪŋ, sɪns ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒəz wəɾ əv ðɛɹ haɪdz ɪf ivən ðə hæf keɪm aʊt, ən wɪð noʊ ɡɹeɪt heɪst, ðeɪ keɪm fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə klʌstɝ ɝaʊn hɝ, ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɔl mæsks ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi ən peɪʃəns. ðən ɛɡwin toʊl dɛlænə tə ɹɪpit wʌt ʃi hæd sɛd. fəɹ ɔl əɹ ɪnɪʃəl ɹɪkwɛs fəɹ pɹaɪvəsi, ðə ɡɹeɪ meɪɾ oʊnli ə pɝfʌŋktɝi dɪmɹəl bɪfɔɹ kəmplaɪɪŋ. ən ðət wɑz ði ɛn ə kɑm ən peɪʃəns.

They were smart enough to keep the secrets that needed keeping, since their own Ajahs would have their hides if even the half came out, and with no great haste, they came forward and rode in a cluster around her, their faces all masks of Aes Sedai serenity and patience. Then Egwene told Delana to repeat what she had said. For all her initial request for privacy, the Gray made only a perfunctory demurral before complying. And that was the end of calm and patience.

"ðæts mædnəs," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. ʃi saʊndəɾ æŋɡɹi, ən pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl fɹaɪɾənd. wɛl ʃi maɪt bi. hɝ neɪm wɑz ɑn ə lɪst ə ðoʊz mɑɹk fəɹ stɪlɪŋ.

"That's madness," Sheriam said before anyone else could open her mouth. She sounded angry, and perhaps a little frightened. Well she might be. Her name was on a list of those marked for stilling.

"nʌn ə ðɛm kən ɹɪli bɪliv nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən ɪz pɑsəbəl." "aɪ ʃəd hɑɹdli θɪŋk soʊ," æneɪjə pʊɾ ɪn dʒɹaɪli. hɝ pleɪn feɪs bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə fɑɹmwaɪf ɹæðɝ ðən ə blu sɪstɝ, ən ʃi dʒɹɛs vɛɹi sɪmpli, pʌblɪkli ət list, ɪn ɡʊd wʊl, bʌt ʃi hændəld əɹ beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ əz izəli əz dɛlænə dɪɾ əɹ mɛɹ. vɛɹi lɪɾəl kəd ɹʌfəl æneɪjəz kɑm. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ blu əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz tɔkɪŋ nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən.

"None of them can really believe negotiation is possible." "I should hardly think so," Anaiya put in dryly. Her plain face belonged on a farmwife rather than a Blue sister, and she dressed very simply, publicly at least, in good wool, but she handled her bay gelding as easily as Delana did her mare. Very little could ruffle Anaiya's calm. Of course, there was no Blue among the Sitters talking negotiation.

æneɪjə lʊkt ən ənlaɪkli soʊlʒɝ, bʌt fəɹ bluz, ðɪs wɑz wɔɹ tə ðə naɪf, noʊ kɔɹɾɝ æskt əɹ ɡɪvən.

Anaiya looked an unlikely soldier, but for Blues, this was war to the knife, no quarter asked or given.

"ɪleɪɾə hæz meɪd ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən kwaɪt klɪɹ."

"Elaida has made the situation quite clear."

"ɪleɪɾə ɪz ɪɹæʃənəl," kɑɹlɪnjə sɛd wɪð ə tɔs ə hɝ hɛd ðət meɪɾ əɹ kaʊl fɔl tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ən ʃʊk əɹ ʃɔɹt dɑɹk kɝlz. ʃi pʊl ðə hʊd bæk ɪndə pleɪs ɪɹɪɾəbli. kɑɹlɪnjə sɛldəm ʃoʊɾ ɛni hɪn ʌv ɪmoʊʃən, jɛɾ əɹ peɪl tʃiks wɝ nɪɹli əz flʌʃt əz ʃɛɹiəmz, ən hit fɪld əɹ vɔɪs. "ʃi kænɑt pɑsəbli bɪliv ðət wɪl ɔl kʌm kɹɔlɪŋ bæk tə hɝ naʊ. haʊ kən sɛɝɔɪjə bɪliv ʃɪl æksɛpt ɛniθɪŋ lɛs?" "kɹɔlɪŋ ɪz wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə hæz dɪmændəd, ðoʊ," mɔɹvɹɪn mʌɾɝd ækɹɪdli. hɝ juʒəwəli plæsəd ɹaʊn feɪs wɔɹ ə saʊɝ ɪkspɝz sən, tu, ən əɹ plʌmp hænz wɝ taɪɾ ɑn əɹ ɹeɪnz. ʃi skaʊl soʊ hɑɹɾ əɾ ə flaɪɾ ə mæɡpaɪz, skæɾɝɪŋ fɹəm ə stæn ə bɝtʃ tʃɹiz ət ðə pæsədʒ ə hɔɹsəz, ðəɾ ɪt sim ðeɪ ʃəd fɔl aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ. "tɑkimə laɪks ðə saʊn ə hɝ oʊn vɔɪs, səmtaɪmz. ʃi mʌs bi tɔkɪŋ tə hɪɹ hɝsɛlf."

"Elaida is irrational," Carlinya said with a toss of her head that made her cowl fall to her shoulders and shook her short dark curls. She pulled the hood back into place irritably. Carlinya seldom showed any hint of emotion, yet her pale cheeks were nearly as flushed as Sheriam's, and heat filled her voice. "She cannot possibly believe that we will all come crawling back to her now. How can Saroiya believe she will accept anything less?" "Crawling is what Elaida has demanded, though," Morvrin muttered acridly. Her usually placid round face wore a sour expres sion, too, and her plump hands were tight on her reins. She scowled so hard at a flight of magpies, scattering from a stand of birch trees at the passage of horses, that it seemed they should fall out of the sky. "Takima likes the sound of her own voice, sometimes. She must be talking to hear herself."

"feɪsɛl mʌst, tu," maɪɹɛl sɛd dɑɹkli, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət dɛlænə əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ tə bleɪm. ði ɑləv-skɪnd wʊmən wɑz noʊn fəɹ əɹ tɛmpɝ, ivən əmʌŋ ɡɹinz. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə hɪɹ ðət sɔɹɾ ə tɔk aʊɾ ə hɝ. ʃiz nɛvɝ bɪn ə ful bɪfɔɹ." "aɪ kæn bɪliv mæɡlə ɹɪli minz ɛni sətʃ θɪŋ," naɪsaʊ ɪnsɪstəd, piɹɪŋ əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn. "ʃi dʒʌs kænt. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ heɪt tə seɪ ɪt, ɹoʊmændə hæz mæɡlə soʊ taɪɾ ʌndɝ əɹ θʌm ðət mæɡlə skwiks wɛnɛvɝ ɹoʊmændə snizɪz, ən ði oʊnli daʊt ɹoʊmændə hæz ɪz wɛðɝ ɪleɪɾə ʃəd bi bɝtʃt bɪfɔɹ ʃiz ɛɡzaɪld." dɛlænəz ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz soʊ blænd, ʃi hæd tə bi səpɹɛsɪŋ ə smʌɡ smaɪl. pleɪnli, ðɪs wɑz ɪɡzækli ðə ɹiækʃən ʃi hæd hoʊp fɔɹ. "ɹoʊmændə hoʊlz sɛɝɔɪjə ən vɛɹɪlɪn dʒʌst əz fɝmli, ən tɑkimə ən feɪsɛl hɑɹdli pʊt wʌn fʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪθaʊt ləleɪnz pɝmɪʃən, bʌt ðeɪ stɪl sɛd wʌt ðeɪ sɛd. aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ ædvaɪzɝz ɑɹ kloʊsɝ tə ðə filɪŋz ə moʊst sɪstɝz, ðoʊ, mʌðɝ." smuðɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌvz, ʃi ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "ju meɪ bi eɪbəl tə nɪp ðɪs ɪn ðə bʌd, ɪf jə muv fɝmli. ɪt simz jəl əv ðə səpɔɹt jə nid fɹəm ði ədʒəz. ən maɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪn ðə hɔl. maɪn, ən ɪnʌf mɔɹ tə stɑp ɪt dɛd." əz ɪf ɛɡwin niɾəd səpɔɹt tə əkɑmplɪʃ ðæt. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪt hɝsɛlf. əɹ dʒʌs tə meɪk ɪɾ əpɪɹ ðət səpɔɹɾ ʌv ɛɡwin wɑz əɹ oʊnli kənsɝn.

"Faiselle must, too," Myrelle said darkly, glaring at Delana as though she were to blame. The olive-skinned woman was known for her temper, even among Greens. "I never expected to hear that sort of talk out of her. She's never been a fool before." "I can't believe Magla really means any such thing," Nisao insisted, peering at each of them in turn. "She just can't. For one thing, as much as I hate to say it, Romanda has Magla so tight under her thumb that Magla squeaks whenever Romanda sneezes, and the only doubt Romanda has is whether Elaida should be birched before she's exiled." Delana's expression was so bland, she had to be suppressing a smug smile. Plainly, this was exactly the reaction she had hoped for. "Romanda holds Saroiya and Varilin just as firmly, and Takima and Faiselle hardly put one foot in front of the other without Lelaine's permission, but they still said what they said. I think your advisors are closer to the feelings of most sisters, though, Mother." Smoothing her gloves, she gave Egwene a sidelong look. "You may be able to nip this in the bud, if you move firmly. It seems you will have the support you need from the Ajahs. And mine, of course, in the Hall. Mine, and enough more to stop it dead." As if Egwene needed support to accomplish that. Perhaps she was trying to ingratiate herself. Or just to make it appear that support of Egwene was her only concern.

bioʊnɪn hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn saɪləns, klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ən piɹɪŋ əɾ ə spɑt bɪtwin əɹ bɹaʊn mɛɹz ɪɹz, bʌt sʌɾənli ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɔɹɾənɛɹəli, hɝ lɑɹdʒ blu-ɡɹeɪ aɪz meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ stɑɹɾəld, bʌt ðeɪ pɪɹd fɹəm əɹ hʊɾ ɪn ə bleɪz ʌv æŋɡɝ əz ʃi ɡlɛɹd fɹəm wʌn ə hɝ kəmpænjənz tə ənʌðɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɛɡwin. "waɪ ʃəd nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz bi aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən?" ʃɛɹiəm blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən mɔɹvɹɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ wɪð ə skaʊl, bʌt bioʊnɪn plʌnʒd ɑn, dɝɛktɪŋ əɹ aɪɹ ət dɛlænə, naʊ, hɝ tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛn stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən juʒəwəl. "wi ɑɹ ɡɹeɪ, jə ən aɪ. wi nəɡoʊʃieɪt, miɾieɪt. ɪleɪɾə, ʃiz steɪɾəd ðə kəndɪʃənz moʊst oʊnɝəs, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ɔfən ðə keɪs ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. wi kən ɹiunaɪt ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən əʃʊɹ ðə seɪfti ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn, ɪf wi oʊnli tɔk."

Beonin had been riding in silence, clutching her cloak around her and peering at a spot between her brown mare's ears, but suddenly she shook her head. Ordinarily, her large blue-gray eyes made her appear startled, but they peered from her hood in a blaze of anger as she glared from one of her companions to another, including Egwene. "Why should negotiations be out of the question?" Sheriam blinked at her in surprise, and Morvrin opened her mouth with a scowl, but Beonin plunged on, directing her ire at Delana, now, her Taraboner accent stronger than usual. "We are Gray, you and I. We negotiate, mediate. Elaida, she has stated the conditions most onerous, but that is often the case in the beginning of negotiations. We can reunite the White Tower and assure the safety of everyone, if we only talk."

"wi ɔlsoʊ dʒʌdʒ," dɛlænə snæpt, "æn ɪleɪɾə hæz bɪn dʒʌdʒd." ðət wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli tʃɹu, bʌt ʃi simd mɔɹ stɑɹɾəld ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls baɪ bioʊnɪnz aʊtbɝst. hɝ vɔɪs dʒɹɪpt æsəd. "pɝhæps jə ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə nəɡoʊʃieɪt jɝsɛlf ɪndə biɪŋ bɝtʃt. aɪm nɑt, ən aɪ θɪŋk jəl faɪn fju ʌðɝz u ɑɹ, iðɝ." "ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, ɪts ɔltɝd," bioʊnɪn pɝsɪstəd. ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt ə hæn təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin, ɔlmoʊs pliɾɪŋ. "ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑɾ əv meɪd ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən ʃi dɪd kənsɝnɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ənlɛs ʃi hæɾ ɪm ɪn hænd, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ðət flɛɹ ɑfseɪaɪdɑɹ wɑz ə wɔɹnɪŋ. ðə fɔɹseɪkən mʌs bi muvɪŋ, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪt mʌs bi - " "ɪnʌf," ɛɡwin kʌɾ ɪn. "ju ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə oʊpən nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪð ɪleɪɾə? wɪð ðə sɪɾɝz stɪl ɪn ðə taʊɝ?" ʃi əmɛndəd. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɛvɝ tɔk.

"We also judge," Delana snapped, "and Elaida has been judged." That was not precisely true, but she seemed more startled than anyone else by Beonin's outburst. Her voice dripped acid. "Perhaps you are willing to negotiate yourself into being birched. I am not, and I think you will find few others who are, either." "The situation, it has altered," Beonin persisted. She stretched a hand toward Egwene, almost pleading. "Elaida would not have made the proclamation she did concerning the Dragon Reborn unless she had him in hand, one way or another. That flare ofsaidar was a warning. The Forsaken must be moving, and the White Tower, it must be - " "Enough," Egwene cut in. "You are willing to open negotiations with Elaida? With the Sitters still in the Tower?" she amended. Elaida would never talk.

"jɛs," bioʊnɪn sɛd fɝvənli. "mæɾɝz kən bi ɝeɪnʒd tə ɛvɹiwʌnz sæɾəsfækʃən. aɪ noʊ ðeɪ kæn."

"Yes," Beonin said fervently. "Matters can be arranged to everyone's satisfaction. I know they can."

"ðɛn juv maɪ pɝmɪʃən."

"Then you have my permission."

ɪmiɾiətli ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt bioʊnɪn bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ fɹæntəkəli ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsweɪd hɝ, tɛlɪŋ əɹ ðɪs wɑz ɪnsænəɾi. æneɪjə ʃaʊɾəd əz laʊdli əz ʃɛɹiəm, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɛmfæɾɪkli, ən dɛlænəz aɪz bʌlʒd ɪn wʌt lʊk laɪk nɪɹ tɛɹɝ. səm ə ði aʊtʃɹaɪɾɝz bɪɡæn lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɪstɝz əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ wɑtʃt ðə fɑɹmz ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæst, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝz, hu sɝɾənli hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðɛɹ bɑnz ət ðə moʊmən tə noʊ ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ædʒəteɪɾəd, bʌt ðeɪ hɛl ðɛɹ pleɪsəz. waɪz mɛn kɛp ðɛɹ noʊzɪz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ wən ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪɡæn ɹeɪzɪŋ ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz.

Immediately everyone but Beonin began talking frantically on top of one another, trying to dissuade her, telling her this was insanity. Anaiya shouted as loudly as Sheriam, gesturing emphatically, and Delana's eyes bulged in what looked like near terror. Some of the outriders began looking toward the sisters as much as they watched the farms they were riding past, and there was a stir among the Warders, who certainly had no need of their bonds at the moment to know their Aes Sedai were agitated, but they held their places. Wise men kept their noses out of the way when Aes Sedai began raising their voices.

ɛɡwin ɪɡnɔɹd ðə ʃaʊts ən ɑɹm-weɪvɪŋ. ʃi hæd kənsɪɾɝd ɛvɹi pɑsəbɪləɾi ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə fəɹ ɛndɪŋ ðɪs stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ hoʊl ən junaɪɾəd. ʃi hæd tɔk fəɹ aʊɝz wɪð sɪuən, hu hæd mɔɹ ɹizən ðən ɛniwʌn tə wɑnə ənsiɾ ɪleɪɾə. ɪf ɪt cʊɾə seɪv ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin wʊɾə sɝɛndɝd tə ɪleɪɾə, fɝɡɛt wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən hæd kʌm tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit liɡəli. sɪuən hæd nɪɹli hæɾ æpəplɛksi ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən, jɛt ʃi hæɾ əɡɹid, ɹɪlʌktənli, ðət pɹəzɝvɪŋ ðə taʊɝ supɝsiɾəd ɛvɹi ʌðɝ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən. bioʊnɪn wɔɹ sətʃ ə bjuɾəfəl smaɪl, ɪt simd ə kɹaɪm tə kwɛntʃ ɪt.

Egwene ignored the shouts and arm-waving. She had considered every possibility she could think of for ending this struggle with the White Tower whole and united. She had talked for hours with Siuan, who had more reason than anyone to want to unseat Elaida. If it could have saved the Tower, Egwene would have surrendered to Elaida, forget whether the woman had come to the Amyrlin Seat legally. Siuan had nearly had apoplexy at the suggestion, yet she had agreed, reluctantly, that preserving the Tower superseded every other consideration. Beonin wore such a beautiful smile, it seemed a crime to quench it.

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ði ʌðɝz. "ju wɪl əpɹoʊtʃ vɛɹɪlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz dɛlænə neɪmd, ən ɝeɪnʒ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðiz ɑɹ ðə tɝmz əl æksɛpt: ɪleɪɾə ɪz tə ɹɪzaɪn ən ɡoʊ ɪndə ɛɡzaɪl." kəz ɪleɪɾə wəd nɛvɝ æksɛp bæk ðə sɪstɝz u hæd ɹɪbɛld əɡɛns hɝ. ən æmɪɝlɪn hæd noʊ seɪ oʊvɝ haʊ ən ədʒɑ ɡʌvɝn ɪtsɛlf, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə hæd dɪklɛɹd ðət ðə sɪstɝz u flɛd ðə taʊɝ wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mɛmbɝz ʌv ɛni ədʒɑ. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɝ, ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə bɛɡ ɹidmɪɾəns tə ðɛɹ ədʒəz, æftɝ sɝvɪŋ ə pɛnəns ʌndɝ əɹ dɝɛkt kəntʃɹoʊl. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑt ɹiunaɪt ðə taʊɝ, oʊnli ʃæɾɝ ɪt wɝs ðən ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz. "ðoʊz ɑɹ ði oʊnli tɝmz əl æksɛpt, bioʊnɪn. ði oʊnli tɝmz. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?" bioʊnɪnz aɪz ɹoʊld ʌp ɪn əɹ hɛd, ən ʃi wʊɾə fɔlən fɹəm əɹ hɔɹs ɪf mɔɹvɹɪn hæd nɑt kɑt hɝ, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əz ʃi hɛl ðə ɡɹeɪ əpɹaɪɾ ən slæpt əɹ feɪs, nɑt laɪtli. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls stɛɹɾ əɾ ɛɡwin əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin əɹ bɪfɔɹ. ivən dɛlænə, hu mʌst əv plæn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs tə hæpən fɹəm ðə fɝst wɝd ʃi hæd sɛd. ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə ə hɔlt wɪð bioʊnɪnz feɪntɪŋ fɪt, ən ðə ɹɪŋ ə soʊlʒɝz ɝaʊn əm dʒɹu ʌp əɾ ə ʃaʊɾəd kəmæn fɹəm lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ. səm stɛɹd təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðɛɹ æŋzaɪəɾi pleɪn ivən wɪð ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts. "ɪts taɪm tə ɡɛt bæk tə kæmp," ɛɡwin sɛd. kɑmli. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn hæd tə bi dʌn. pɝhæps sɝɛndɝ wʊɾə hil ðə taʊɝ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ən naʊ ɪt maɪt kʌm daʊn tə ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ənlɛs ʃi kəd faɪn ə weɪ tə meɪk əɹ plæn səksid. "wi hæv wɝk tə du," ʃi sɛd, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz, "æn ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ taɪm lɛft." ʃi pɹeɪd ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf.

Egwene raised her voice just enough to be heard over the others. "You will approach Varilin and the others Delana named, and arrange to approach the White Tower. These are the terms I will accept: Elaida is to resign and go into exile." Because Elaida would never accept back the sisters who had rebelled against her. An Amyrlin had no say over how an Ajah governed itself, but Elaida had declared that the sisters who fled the Tower were no longer members of any Ajah. According to her, they would have to beg readmittance to their Ajahs, after serving a penance under her direct control. Elaida would not reunite the Tower, only shatter it worse than it already was. "Those are the only terms I will accept, Beonin. The only terms. Do you understand me?" Beonin's eyes rolled up in her head, and she would have fallen from her horse if Morvrin had not caught her, muttering under her breath as she held the Gray upright and slapped her face, not lightly. Everyone else stared at Egwene as though they had never seen her before. Even Delana, who must have planned for something like this to happen from the first word she had said. They had come to a halt with Beonin's fainting fit, and the ring of soldiers around them drew up at a shouted command from Lord Gareth. Some stared toward the Aes Sedai, their anxiety plain even with their faces hidden behind the bars of their helmets. "It's time to get back to camp," Egwene said. Calmly. What had to be done had to be done. Perhaps surrender would have healed the Tower, but she could not believe it. And now it might come down to Aes Sedai facing one another in the streets of Tar Valon, unless she could find a way to make her plan succeed. "We have work to do," she said, gathering her reins, "and there isn't much time left." She prayed there was enough.

tʃæptɝ sɛvəntin

CHAPTER 17

sikɹəts wʌns dɛlænə wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ əɹ nɑkʃəs sid hæd teɪkən ɹut, ʃi mɝmɝd ðəɾ ɪt maɪt bi bɛst ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt sin ɝaɪvɪŋ bæk ət ðə kæmp təɡɛðɝ ən slɪpt əweɪ, pʊʃɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ tə ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt θɹu ðə snoʊ ən livɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm tə ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪn ənizi saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə kɹʌntʃ ə ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz. ðə wɔɹɾɝz meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ dɪstəns bɪhaɪnd, ən ði ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz hæd ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən bæk ɑn ðə fɑɹmz ən θɪkəts, wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɾ ɛɡwin kəd si, naʊ. mɛn nɛvɝ nu wən tə kip ðɛɹ maʊðz ʃʌt, ðoʊ. tɛlɪŋ ə mæn tə bi kwaɪəɾ oʊnli meɪɾ ɪm ɡɑsəp ɔl ðə hɑɹɾɝ, dʒʌs tə kloʊz fɹɛnz i kəd tʃɹʌst, tə bi ʃʊɹ, əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪn tɝn wəd nɑt tɛl ɛvɹiwʌn u wəd lɪsən. ðə wɔɹɾɝz maɪt bi dɪfɹənt - ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz ɪnsɪstəd ðeɪ wɝ, ðoʊz u hæd wɔɹɾɝz - bʌt noʊ daʊt ðə soʊlʒɝz wəd tɔk ə sɪstɝz ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, ən noʊ daʊt ðeɪ wəd seɪ dɛlænə hæd bɪn sɛn ɔf wɪð ə fli ɪn əɹ ɪɹ. ðə wʊmən hæd plæn ðɪs vɛɹi kɛɹfəli.

Secrets Once Delana was sure that her noxious seed had taken root, she murmured that it might be best if they were not seen arriving back at the camp together and slipped away, pushing her mare to a quick trot through the snow and leaving the rest of them to ride on in uneasy silence except for the crunch of the horses' hooves. The Warders maintained their distance behind, and the escorting soldiers had their attention back on the farms and thickets, without so much as a glance toward the Aes Sedai that Egwene could see, now. Men never knew when to keep their mouths shut, though. Telling a man to be quiet only made him gossip all the harder, just to close friends he could trust, to be sure, as if they in turn would not tell everyone who would listen. The Warders might be different - Aes Sedai always insisted they were, those who had Warders - but no doubt the soldiers would talk of sisters arguing, and no doubt they would say Delana had been sent off with a flea in her ear. The woman had planned this very carefully.

wɝs ðən faɪɝwiɾ əɹ stʃɹæŋɡlɝvaɪn kəd ɡɹoʊ ɪf ðət sid wɑz əlaʊd tə spɹaʊt, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪɾɝ hæd ʃɛltɝd hɝsɛlf fɹəm bleɪm vɛɹi nitli. tʃɹuθ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz dɪd kʌm aʊɾ ɪn ði ɛnd, bʌt baɪ ði ɛnd, tʃɹuθ wɑz ɔfən soʊ ɹæpt ɝaʊnd wɪð ɹumɝz ən spɛkjəleɪʃən ən æbsəlut laɪz ðət moʊs pipəl nɛvɝ dɪd bɪliv ɪt.

Worse than fireweed or stranglervine could grow if that seed was allowed to sprout, but the Gray Sitter had sheltered herself from blame very neatly. Truth almost always did come out in the end, but by the end, truth was often so wrapped around with rumors and speculation and absolute lies that most people never did believe it.

"aɪ tʃɹʌst aɪ doʊn əv tə æsk wɛðɝ ɛni ʌv jə hæd hɝɾ əbaʊt ðɪs bɪfɔɹ." ɛɡwin sɛd ðət kwaɪt kæʒəwəli, simɪŋli stʌɾiɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, bʌt ʃi wɑz plizd wən ɛvɹiwʌn dɪnaɪɾ ɪɾ aʊtʃɹaɪt wɪð kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ bioʊnɪn, hu wɑz wɝkɪŋ əɹ dʒɔ ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət mɔɹvɹɪn. ɛɡwin tʃɹʌstɪɾ əm əz fɑɹ əz ʃi dɛɹd - ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv ɡɪvən əɹ ðɛɹ oʊðz wɪθaʊt minɪŋ tə hoʊl tə ɛvɹi wɝd; nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ blæk ədʒɑ, ə nɪɡəlɪŋ pɑsəbɪləɾi ðəɾ əkaʊntəd fəɹ moʊst ə hɝ kɑʃən - jɛɾ ivən oʊðz ə fiəlti lɛft ɹum fəɹ ðə moʊs lɔɪəl pipəl duɪŋ ðə wɝs pɑsəbəl θɪŋ ɪn ðə bɪlif ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɪn jəɹ bɛst ɪntʃɹəst. ən pipəl u hæd bɪn koʊɝst ɪndə ðɛɹ oʊðz kəd bi ədɛpt ət spɑɾɪŋ ðə ɡæps ən liweɪz. "ðə ɹil kwɛstʃən," ʃi kəntɪnjud, "ɪz wʌt wɑz dɛlænə æftɝ?" ʃi hæd noʊ nid tə ɪkspleɪn, nɑt fəɹ ðiz wɪmən, ɛvɹi wʌn ɪkspɪɹiənst ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz. ɪf ɔl dɛlænə hæd wɑntəd wɑz tə stɑp nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪð ɪleɪɾə waɪl kipɪŋ əɹ oʊn neɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, ʃi kəd sɪmpli hæv spoʊkən tə ɛɡwin əloʊn əɾ ɛni taɪm. sɪɾɝz niɾəd noʊ ɪkskjus tə kʌm tə ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi. əɹ ʃi cʊɾə juz hɑlimə, hu slɛpt ɑn ə pæləɾ ɪn ɛɡwinz tɛn moʊs naɪts dɪspaɪt biɪŋ dɛlænəz sɛkɹətɛɹi. ɛɡwin wɑz tʃɹʌbəld wɪð hɛdeɪks, ən səm naɪts oʊnli hɑliməz məsɑʒɪz kəd suð əm soʊ ʃi kəd slip. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ən ənɑnəməs noʊt maɪɾ əv bɪn səfɪʃən tə meɪk əɹ pɹizɛn ðə hɔl wɪð ən iɾɪkt fɝbɪɾɪŋ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ðə tʌtʃiəs kwɪblɝ wəɾ əv tə ədmɪt ðət tɔks tə ɛn ðə wɔɹ sɝɾənli tʌtʃt ɑn ðə wɔɹ. bʌt pleɪnli dɛlænə wɑntəd ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz tə noʊ, tu. hɝ tɑlbɛɹɪŋ wɑz ən æɹoʊ eɪmd əɾ ənʌðɝ tɑɹɡət.

"I trust I don't have to ask whether any of you had heard about this before." Egwene said that quite casually, seemingly studying the countryside as they rode, but she was pleased when everyone denied it outright with considerable indignation, including Beonin, who was working her jaw and glaring at Morvrin. Egwene trusted them as far as she dared - they could not have given her their oaths without meaning to hold to every word; not unless they were Black Ajah, a niggling possibility that accounted for most of her caution - yet even oaths of fealty left room for the most loyal people doing the worst possible thing in the belief that it was in your best interest. And people who had been coerced into their oaths could be adept at spotting the gaps and leeways. "The real question," she continued, "is what was Delana after?" She had no need to explain, not for these women, every one experienced in the Game of Houses. If all Delana had wanted was to stop negotiations with Elaida while keeping her own name out of it, she could simply have spoken to Egwene alone at any time. Sitters needed no excuse to come to the Amyrlin's study. Or she could have used Halima, who slept on a pallet in Egwene's tent most nights despite being Delana's secretary. Egwene was troubled with headaches, and some nights only Halima's massages could soothe them so she could sleep. For that matter, an anonymous note might have been sufficient to make her present the Hall with an edict forbidding negotiations. The touchiest quibbler would have to admit that talks to end the war certainly touched on the war. But plainly Delana wanted Sheriam and the others to know, too. Her talebearing was an arrow aimed at another target.

"stʃɹaɪf bɪtwin ði ədʒɑ hɛdz ən ðə sɪɾɝz," kɑɹlɪnjə sɛd, əz kul əz ðə snoʊ. "pɝhæps stʃɹaɪf bɪtwin ði ədʒəz." kæʒəwəli ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ kloʊk, ɪntʃɹəkətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd waɪt-ɑn-waɪt bʌt laɪnd wɪð dɛns blæk fɝ, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn dɪskʌsɪŋ ðə pɹaɪs ʌv ə spul ə θɹɛd. "waɪ ʃi wɑns ðiz θɪŋz, aɪ kæn bɪɡɪn tə seɪ, bʌt ðoʊz wɪl bi ðə ɹɪzʌls, ənlɛs wəɹ vɛɹi kɛɹfəl, ən ʃi kəd nɑt noʊ wi wəd bi kɛɹfəl, əɹ ðət wɪv ɛni ɹizən tə bi, soʊ lɑdʒɪkli wʌn əɹ boʊθ mʌs bi hɝ eɪm."

"Strife between the Ajah heads and the Sitters," Carlinya said, as cool as the snow. "Perhaps strife between the Ajahs." Casually adjusting her cloak, intricately embroidered white-on-white but lined with dense black fur, she might have been discussing the price of a spool of thread. "Why she wants these things, I can't begin to say, but those will be the results, unless we are very careful, and she could not know we would be careful, or that we have any reason to be, so logically one or both must be her aim."

"ðə fɝst ænsɝ ðət kʌmz tə maɪn ɪzən ɔlweɪz kɝɛkt, kɑɹlɪnjə," mɔɹvɹɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹz noʊ seɪɪŋ ðət dɛlænə θɔɾ əɹ ækʃənz θɹu əz kɛɹfəli əz jə hæv, əɹ ðət ʃi θɔɾ əlɔŋ ðə seɪm laɪnz." ðə staʊt bɹaʊn bɪliv mɔɹ ɪn kɑmən sɛns ðən lɑdʒɪk, əɹ soʊ ʃi sɛd, bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ ʃi sim tə blɛn ðə tu, ə kɑmbəneɪʃən ðət meɪɾ əɹ vɛɹi hɑɹdhɛɾɪd, ən səspɪʃəs ə kwɪk əɹ izi ænsɝz. wɪtʃ wɑz nɑɾ ə bæd θɪŋ tə bi. "dɛlænə meɪ bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sweɪ səm əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ɑn səm ɪʃu ðæts ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ. meɪbi ʃi hoʊps tə ɡɛɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪklɛɹd blæk ədʒɑ æftɝ ɔl. noʊ mæɾɝ ðə ɹɪzʌls, hɝ ɡoʊl meɪ bi sʌmθɪŋ wi doʊn ivən səspɛkt. sɪɾɝz kən bi əz pɛɾi əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. fəɹ ɔl wi noʊ, ʃi maɪɾ əv ə ɡɹʌdʒ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðoʊz ʃi neɪm deɪɾɪŋ bæk tə wən ʃi wɑz ə nɑvəs ən ðeɪ tɔt hɝ. bɛɾɝ tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn wʌt wɪl kʌm ʌv ɪt ðən tə wɝi əbaʊt waɪ əntɪl wi noʊ mɔɹ." hɝ toʊn wɑz əz plæsəɾ əz əɹ bɹɔd feɪs, bʌt kɑɹlɪnjəz kul kəmpoʊʒɝ flɪkɝd tə kul dɪsdeɪn fəɹ ə moʊmənt. hɝ ɹæʃənælɪɾi meɪd fju kənsɛʃənz fəɹ hjumən fɔɪbəlz. əɹ fəɹ ɛniwʌn dɪsəɡɹiɪŋ wɪð hɝ.

"The first answer that comes to mind isn't always correct, Carlinya," Morvrin said. "There's no saying that Delana thought her actions through as carefully as you have, or that she thought along the same lines." The stout Brown believed more in common sense than logic, or so she said, but in truth she seemed to blend the two, a combination that made her very hardheaded, and suspicious of quick or easy answers. Which was not a bad thing to be. "Delana may be trying to sway some among the Sitters on some issue that's important to her. Maybe she hopes to get Elaida declared Black Ajah after all. No matter the results, her goal may be something we don't even suspect. Sitters can be as petty as anyone else. For all we know, she might have a grudge against one of those she named dating back to when she was a novice and they taught her. Better to concentrate on what will come of it than to worry about why until we know more." Her tone was as placid as her broad face, but Carlinya's cool composure flickered to cool disdain for a moment. Her rationality made few concessions for human foibles. Or for anyone disagreeing with her.

æneɪjə læft, ə saʊn ʌv ɔlmoʊs mʌðɝli əmjuzmən ðət meɪɾ əɹ beɪ dæns ə fju stɛps bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹeɪn ɪm bæk tə ə wɔk. ə mʌðɝli fɑɹmwaɪf əmjuz baɪ ði æntɪks ʌv ʌðɝz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ.

Anaiya laughed, a sound of almost motherly amusement that made her bay dance a few steps before she reined him back to a walk. A motherly farmwife amused by the antics of others in the village.

ivən səm sɪstɝz wɝ fulɪʃ ɪnʌf tə dɪsmɪs əɹ ðəɾ izəli. "doʊn sʌlk, kɑɹlɪnjə. jə ɑɹ vɛɹi pɹɑbli ɹaɪt. noʊ, mɔɹvɹɪn, ʃi pɹɑbli ɪz. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, aɪ bɪliv wi kən skwɑʃ ɛni hoʊps ʃiz fəɹ dɪskɔɹd." ðət dɪd nɑt saʊn əmjuzd əɾ ɔl. noʊ blu wɑz əmjuz baɪ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt hæmpɝ pʊlɪŋ ɪleɪɾə daʊn.

Even some sisters were foolish enough to dismiss her that easily. "Don't sulk, Carlinya. You are very probably right. No, Morvrin, she probably is. In any event, I believe we can squash any hopes she has for discord." That did not sound amused at all. No Blue was amused by anything that might hamper pulling Elaida down.

maɪɹɛl ɡeɪv ə sævədʒ nɑɾ ʌv əɡɹimənt, ðən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz wən naɪsaʊ sɛd, "kæn jə əfɔɹd tə stɑp ðɪs, mʌðɝ?" ðə taɪni jɛloʊ dɪd nɑt spik ʌp ɔfən. "aɪ doʊn min wʌtɛvɝ dɛlænə ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du. ɪf wi kən sɛɾəl ɑn wʌt ðəɾ ɪz," ʃi æɾəd kwɪkli, meɪkɪŋ ə dʒɛstʃɝ ət mɔɹvɹɪn, hu hæɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn. naɪsaʊ lʊkt ə tʃaɪld əlɔŋsaɪd ði ʌðɝ wɪmən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə pɝɛmptɝi dʒɛstʃɝ. ʃi wɑz jɛloʊ, æftɝ ɔl, wɪð ɔl ðə sɛlfəʃʊɹəns ðəɾ ɪmplaɪd, ən ənwɪlɪŋ tə stɛp bæk fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɪn moʊst sɝkəmstænsəz. "aɪ min ðə tɔk ə pɑɹli wɪð ðə sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə taʊɝ." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɛvɹiwʌn ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, ivən bioʊnɪn. "ænd waɪ wəd wi wɑnə əlaʊ ðæt?" æneɪjə sɛd faɪnəli, ɪn ə deɪnʒɝəs vɔɪs. "wi dɪdn kʌm ɔl ðɪs weɪ tə tɔk tə ɪleɪɾə." ʃi wɑz ə fɑɹmwaɪf wɪð ə klivɝ hɪɾən bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk ən ə maɪn tə juz ɪt, naʊ.

Myrelle gave a savage nod of agreement, then blinked in surprise when Nisao said, "Can you afford to stop this, Mother?" The tiny Yellow did not speak up often. "I don't mean whatever Delana is trying to do. If we can settle on what that is," she added quickly, making a gesture at Morvrin, who had opened her mouth again. Nisao looked a child alongside the other women, but it was a peremptory gesture. She was Yellow, after all, with all the selfassurance that implied, and unwilling to step back for anyone in most circumstances. "I mean the talk of parley with the Sitters in the Tower." For a moment, everyone gaped at her, even Beonin. "And why would we want to allow that?" Anaiya said finally, in a dangerous voice. "We didn't come all this way to talk to Elaida." She was a farmwife with a cleaver hidden behind her back and a mind to use it, now.

naɪsaʊ lʊkt ʌp əɾ əɹ ən snɪf dɪsmɪsɪvli. "aɪ dɪdn seɪ wi wɑntəɾ ɪt. aɪ æskt wɛðɝ wi dɛɹ stɑp ɪt." "aɪ hɑɹdli si ðə dɪfɝəns." ʃɛɹiəmz vɔɪs wɑz aɪsi, ən əɹ feɪs peɪl. wɪð æŋɡɝ, ɛɡwin θɔt, bʌɾ ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn fɪɹ.

Nisao looked up at her and sniffed dismissively. "I didn't say we wanted it. I asked whether we dare stop it." "I hardly see the difference." Sheriam's voice was icy, and her face pale. With anger, Egwene thought, but it might have been fear.

"ðɛn θɪŋk fəɹ ə waɪl, ən jə maɪt si ɪt," naɪsaʊ sɛd dʒɹaɪli. dʒɹaɪ ðə weɪ ə naɪf-bleɪd wɑz dʒɹaɪ, ən ikwəli kʌɾɪŋ. "æt pɹɛzənt, tɔk ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ɪz lɪməɾəd tə faɪv sɪɾɝz, ən vɛɹi kwaɪət, bʌt wɪl ɪt ɹɪmeɪn soʊ? wʌns wɝd spɹɛdz ðət tɔks wɝ pɹəpoʊzd ən ɹɪdʒɛktɪd, haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ dɪspɛɹ sɛts ɪn? noʊ, hɪɹ mi aʊt! wi ɔl sɛɾ ɔf fʊl ə ɹaɪtʃəs fjʊɹi fəɹ dʒʌstəs, jɛt hɪɹ wi sɪt, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɔlz ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, waɪl ɪleɪɾə sɪts ɪn ðə taʊɝ. wiv bɪn hɪɹ nɪɹli tu wiks, ən fəɹ ɔl ɛniwʌn kən si, wi meɪ bi hɪɹ tu jɪɹz, əɹ twɛnti. ðə lɔŋɡɝ wi sɪt wɪð nʌθɪŋ hæpənɪŋ, ðə mɔɹ sɪstɝz wɪl stɑɹt meɪkɪŋ ɪkskjusɪz fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz kɹaɪmz. ðə mɔɹ ðəl stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ ðət wɪv tə mɛn ðə taʊɝ, nɛvɝ maɪn ðə kɑst. dʒju wɑnə weɪɾ əntɪl sɪstɝz stɑɹt slɪpɪŋ bæk tə ɪleɪɾə wʌn baɪ wʌn? aɪ maɪsɛlf də nɑt fænsi stændɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk dɪfaɪɪŋ ðə wʊmən wɪð dʒʌs ðə blu ədʒɑ ən ðə ɹɛst ə jə fəɹ kʌmpəni. nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪl ət lis lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn si ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ."

"Then think for a while, and you might see it," Nisao said dryly. Dry the way a knife-blade was dry, and equally cutting. "At present, talk of negotiations is limited to five Sitters, and very quiet, but will it remain so? Once word spreads that talks were proposed and rejected, how long before despair sets in? No, hear me out! We all set off full of righteous fury for justice, yet here we sit, staring at the walls of Tar Valon, while Elaida sits in the Tower. We've been here nearly two weeks, and for all anyone can see, we may be here two years, or twenty. The longer we sit with nothing happening, the more sisters will start making excuses for Elaida's crimes. The more they'll start thinking that we have to mend the Tower, never mind the cost. Do you want to wait until sisters start slipping back to Elaida one by one? I myself do not fancy standing on the riverbank defying the woman with just the Blue Ajah and the rest of you for company. Negotiations will at least let everyone see that something is happening."

"noʊ wʌn ɪz gɑnə ɹɪtɝn tə ɪleɪɾə," æneɪjə pɹətɛstəd, ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn əɹ sæɾəl, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ ə tʃɹʌbəl fɹaʊn, ən ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd si ɪt hæpənɪŋ. ðə taʊɝ bɛkən tə ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ. vɛɹi laɪkli ivən blæk sɪstɝz jɝn fəɹ ðə taʊɝ tə bi hoʊl əɡɛn. ən ðəɹ ɪt stʊd, dʒʌst ə fju maɪlz əweɪ, bʌt simɪŋli aʊɾ ə ɹitʃ.

"No one is going to return to Elaida," Anaiya protested, shifting on her saddle, but she wore a troubled frown, and she sounded as if she could see it happening. The Tower beckoned to every Aes Sedai. Very likely even Black sisters yearned for the Tower to be whole again. And there it stood, just a few miles away, but seemingly out of reach.

"tɔk kəd baɪ taɪm, mʌðɝ," mɔɹvɹɪn sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli, ən noʊ wʌn kəd pʊɾ əz mʌtʃ ɹɪlʌktəns ɪn əɹ vɔɪs əz ʃi. hɝ fɹaʊn wɑz θɔtfəl, ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plizd. "ə fju mɔɹ wiks, ən lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ðə ʃɪps i nidz tə blɑk ðə hɑɹbɝz. ðət wɪl ɔltɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪn əɹ feɪvɝ. wɪð noʊ weɪ fəɹ fud tə ɡɛɾ ɪn əɹ maʊðz tə ɡɛɾ aʊt, ðə sɪɾi wɪl bi stɑɹvɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ə mʌnθ." ɛɡwin hʌŋ ɑn tə ə smuð feɪs wɪð ən ɛfɝt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil hoʊp ə ʃɪps tə blɑk ðə hɑɹbɝ, ðoʊ nʌn kf əm nu ðæt. ɡɛɹɪθ hæd meɪɾ ɪt pleɪn ɪnʌf tə hɝ, haʊɛvɝ, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ mʊɹændi. ɝɪdʒənəli, hi hæd hoʊp tə baɪ vɛsəlz waɪl ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt nɔɹθ əlɔŋ ði ɛɹɪnɪn, juzɪŋ əm tə fɛɹi səplaɪz əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt tɑɹ vəlɑn, ðən sɪŋkɪŋ əm ɪn ðə hɑɹbɝ maʊðz.

"Talk could buy time, Mother," Morvrin said reluctantly, and no one could put as much reluctance in her voice as she. Her frown was thoughtful, and not at all pleased. "A few more weeks, and Lord Gareth might be able to find the ships he needs to block the harbors. That will alter everything, in our favor. With no way for food to get in or mouths to get out, the city will be starving inside a month." Egwene hung on to a smooth face with an effort. There was no real hope of ships to block the harbor, though none cf them knew that. Gareth had made it plain enough to her, however, long before leaving Murandy. Originally, he had hoped to buy vessels while they marched north along the Erinin, using them to ferry supplies until they reached Tar Valon, then sinking them in the harbor mouths.

juzɪŋ ɡeɪtweɪz tə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn hæd pʊt peɪd tə ðəɾ ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn. wɝɾ ə ðə sidʒ hæd lɛf ðə sɪɾi wɪð ðə fɝst ʃɪps seɪlɪŋ æftɝ ði ɑɹmi ɝaɪvd, ən naʊ, əz fɑɹ nɔɹθ ən saʊθ əz i hæd sɛn ɹaɪɾɝz, ʃɪp kæptənz wɝ kæɹiɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs əʃɔɹ baɪ boʊt, fɹəm æŋkɝədʒɪz wɛl aʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ. noʊ kæptən wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ɹɪsk ðə tʃæns əɹ ʃɪp wəd sɪmpli bi sizd. ɡɛɹɪθ meɪɾ ɪz ɹɪpɔɹts oʊnli tə hɝ, ən ɪz ɔfəsɝz oʊnli tə hɪm, jɛɾ ɛni sɪstɝ cʊɾə noʊn ɪf ʃi tɔkt wɪð ə fju soʊlʒɝz.

Using gateways to reach Tar Valon had put paid to that in more ways than one. Word of the siege had left the city with the first ships sailing after the army arrived, and now, as far north and south as he had sent riders, ship captains were carrying out their business ashore by boat, from anchorages well out in the river. No captain was willing to risk the chance her ship would simply be seized. Gareth made his reports only to her, and his officers only to him, yet any sister could have known if she talked with a few soldiers.

fɔɹtʃənətli, ivən sɪstɝz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹɾɝz ɹɛɹli spoʊk tə soʊlʒɝz. ðeɪ wɝ dʒɛnɝəli əkaʊntəɾ ə θivɪŋ, ənlɛɾɝd lɑɾ u oʊnli beɪð baɪ æksəɾənt, wən ðeɪ hæd tə weɪɾ ə stʃɹim. nɑt ðə kaɪndə mæn ɛni sɪstɝ spɛn taɪm wɪð ɪksɛpt wən kəmpɛl tə. ɪt meɪd kipɪŋ sikɹəts iziɝ, ən səm sikɹəts wɝ ɪsɛnʃəl. ɪnkluɾɪŋ, səmtaɪmz, sikɹəts kɛp fɹəm ðoʊz simɪŋli ɑn jəɹ saɪd. ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ ðət weɪ, bʌt ðət wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə ði ɪnkipɝz dɔɾɝ ʃi hæd bɪn əblaɪdʒ tə liv bɪhaɪnd. ðɪs wɑz ənʌðɝ wɝld, wɪð vɛɹi dɪfɹən ɹulz fɹəm ɛmənz fild. ə mɪsstɛp ðəɹ mɛn ə sʌmənz tə ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl. hɪɹ, ə mɪsstɛp mɛn dɛθ əɹ wɝs, ən fəɹ mɔɹ ðən hɝsɛlf. "ðə sɪɾɝz ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ʃəd bi wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk," kɑɹlɪnjə pʊɾ ɪn, wɪð ə saɪ. "ðeɪ hæv tə noʊ ðət ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðə sidʒ læsts, ðə mɔɹ tʃæns lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ wɪl faɪn ɪz ʃɪps.

Fortunately, even sisters looking for Warders rarely spoke to soldiers. They were generally accounted a thieving, unlettered lot who only bathed by accident, when they had to wade a stream. Not the kind of man any sister spent time with except when compelled to. It made keeping secrets easier, and some secrets were essential. Including, sometimes, secrets kept from those seemingly on your side. She could remember not thinking that way, but that was a part of the innkeeper's daughter she had been obliged to leave behind. This was another world, with very different rules from Emond's Field. A misstep there meant a summons to the Women's Circle. Here, a misstep meant death or worse, and for more than herself. "The Sitters remaining in the Tower should be willing to talk," Carlinya put in, with a sigh. "They have to know that the longer the siege lasts, the more chance Lord Gareth will find his ships.

aɪ kænɑt θɪŋk haʊ lɔŋ ðəl kəntɪnju tɔkɪŋ, ðoʊ, wən ðeɪ ɹilaɪz wi də nɑt min tə sɝɛndɝ."

I cannot think how long they will continue talking, though, when they realize we do not mean to surrender."

"ɪleɪɾə wɪl ɪnsɪst ɑn ðæt," maɪɹɛl mʌɾɝd, jɛt ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, dʒʌs tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, ən ʃɛɹiəm ʃɪvɝd, dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd lɛt ðə koʊl tʌtʃ hɝ.

"Elaida will insist on that," Myrelle muttered, yet she did not seem to be arguing, just talking to herself, and Sheriam shivered, drawing her cloak around her as though she had let the cold touch her.

oʊnli bioʊnɪn lʊk hæpi, sɪɾɪŋ iɡɝ ən əpɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, dɑɹk hʌni hɛɹ fɹeɪmɪŋ ə waɪd smaɪl ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hʊd. ʃi dɪd nɑt pɹɛs əɹ keɪs, haʊɛvɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡʊɾ ət nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən, soʊ ɛvɹiwʌn sɛd, ən nu wən tə weɪt.

Only Beonin looked happy, sitting eager and upright in her saddle, dark honey hair framing a wide smile inside her hood. She did not press her case, however. She was good at negotiation, so everyone said, and knew when to wait.

"aɪ dɪd seɪ jə kəd bɪɡɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. nɑt ðət ʃi hæd mɛn ɪt fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə sɛtdaʊn, jɛɾ ɪf jə wɝ gɑnə lɪv baɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz, ðən jə hæd tə stæn baɪ wʌt jə sɛd. ʃi kəd nɑt weɪt tə hoʊl ði oʊθ ɹɑd. ɪt wəd bi soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ, ðɛn. "dʒʌs meɪk ʃʊɹ jəɹ vɛɹi kɛɹfəl wʌt jə seɪ. ənlɛs ðeɪ θɪŋk wi ɔl ɡɹu wɪŋz tə flaɪ hɪɹ, ðeɪ mʌst səspɛkt wiv ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd tʃɹævlɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ kæn bi sɝɾən ənlɛs sʌmwʌn kənfɝmz ɪt. ɪts bɛɾɝ fəɹ əs ɪf ðeɪ steɪ ənsɝɾən. ðət mʌs bi wʌn sikɹət jə hoʊld əz taɪtli əz jə hoʊl ðə sikɹəɾ ʌv əɹ fɛɹəts ɪn ðə taʊɝ." maɪɹɛl ən æneɪjə dʒɝkt ət ðæt, ən kɑɹlɪnjə lʊkt ɝaʊn əz ðoʊ fɪɹfəl, ðoʊ niðɝ wɔɹɾɝz nɔɹ soʊlʒɝz wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ənlɛs sʌmwʌn ʃaʊɾəd. mɔɹvɹɪn mɪɹli tʊk ɑn ən ivən mɔɹ saʊɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ivən naɪsaʊ lʊkt ə lɪɾəl ɪl, ðoʊ ʃi hæd hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə dɪsɪʒən tə sɛn sɪstɝz bæk tə ðə taʊɝ ɪn sikɹət, səpoʊzədli ænsɝɪŋ ɪleɪɾəz sʌmənz. ðə hɔl maɪt bi hæpi tə lɝn ðət tɛn sɪstɝz wɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʌndɝmaɪn ɪleɪɾə haʊɛvɝ ðeɪ kʊd, ivən ɪf ði ɛfɝt hæd bɔɹn noʊ əpɛɹən fɹut soʊ fɑɹ, bʌt ðə sɪɾɝz wəd moʊs dɛfənətli bi ənhæpi ət ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt hæd bɪn kɛp sikɹət kəz ðiz wɪmən fɪɹd ðət səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz maɪɾ æktʃəli  bi blæk ədʒɑ. əz wɛl fəɹ ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz tə ɹɪvil ðɛɹ oʊðz tə ɛɡwin əz ɹɪvil ðæt. ðə ɹɪzʌls fəɹ əm maɪt nɑt bi vɛɹi dɪfɹənt. ðə hɔl hæd nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɛniwʌn bɝtʃt jɛt, bʌt ðə weɪ moʊst sɪɾɝz tʃeɪft ət ðə bɪɾ oʊvɝ ɛɡwinz kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə wɔɹ, ɪt kəd hɑɹdli kʌm əz ə sɝpɹaɪz ɪf ðeɪ dʒʌmpt ət ðə tʃæns tə ʃoʊ ðeɪ stɪl hæd səm əθɔɹəɾi waɪl saɪməlteɪniəsli ɪkspɹɛsɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ fɔɹsfəli.

"I did say you could begin," Egwene said. Not that she had meant it for more than a setdown, yet if you were going to live by the Three Oaths, then you had to stand by what you said. She could not wait to hold the Oath Rod. It would be so much easier, then. "Just make sure you're very careful what you say. Unless they think we all grew wings to fly here, they must suspect we've rediscovered Traveling, but they can't be certain unless someone confirms it. It's better for us if they stay uncertain. That must be one secret you hold as tightly as you hold the secret of our ferrets in the Tower." Myrelle and Anaiya jerked at that, and Carlinya looked around as though fearful, though neither Warders nor soldiers were close enough to hear unless someone shouted. Morvrin merely took on an even more sour expression. Even Nisao looked a little ill, though she had had nothing to do with the decision to send sisters back to the Tower in secret, supposedly answering Elaida's summons. The Hall might be happy to learn that ten sisters were in the Tower trying to undermine Elaida however they could, even if the effort had borne no apparent fruit so far, but the Sitters would most definitely be unhappy at realizing that it had been kept secret because these women feared that some of the Sitters might actually be Black Ajah. As well for Sheriam and the others to reveal their oaths to Egwene as reveal that. The results for them might not be very different. The Hall had not ordered anyone birched yet, but the way most Sitters chafed at the bit over Egwene's control of the war, it could hardly come as a surprise if they jumped at the chance to show they still had some authority while simultaneously expressing their displeasure forcefully.

bioʊnɪn wɑz əpɛɹənli ði oʊnli wʌn u hæɾ əpoʊz ðət dɪsɪʒən - ət list, əntɪl ɪt bɪkeɪm əpɛɹən ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əhɛɾ ɛniweɪ - bʌt ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ, tu, ən ə taɪtnəs sɛɾəld ɝaʊn əɹ aɪz. ɪn əɹ keɪs, ðə sʌɾən ɹiləzeɪʃən ə dʒʌst wʌt ʃi hæɾ ʌndɝteɪkən maɪɾ əv pleɪɾ ɪts pɑɹt, tu. dʒʌs faɪndɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə taʊɝ u wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk maɪt pɹuv ə dɔntɪŋ tæsk. aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn kəɾ ɔfɝ oʊnli hɪɹseɪ əbaʊɾ ɪvɛns ɪnsaɪd ðə taʊɝ; nuz ə ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf keɪm oʊnli ɪn dʒɹɪbz ən dʒɹæbz, fɹəm sɪstɝz vɛntʃɝɪŋ ɪndə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd tə ɡlɪmps fliɾɪŋ ɹɪflɛkʃənz ə ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld, bʌɾ ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðoʊz skɹæps toʊld ʌv ɪleɪɾə ɹulɪŋ baɪ iɾɪkt ən kəpɹis, wɪð nɑɾ ivən ðə hɔl dɛɹɪŋ tə stæn əɡɛns hɝ. bioʊnɪnz feɪs tʊk ɑn ə ɡɹeɪɪʃ tɪnʒ, tɪl ʃi bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ mɔɹ sɪkli ðən naɪsaʊ. æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝz lʊkt əz blik əz dɛθ. ə weɪv ʌv ɡlum ɹoʊz ɪn ɛɡwin. ðiz wɝ əmʌŋ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə, ivən ðə fʊt-dʒɹæɡɪŋ bioʊnɪn, hu ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə tɔk ɹæðɝ ðən ækt. wɛl, ɡɹeɪz wɝ noʊɾəd fəɹ bɪlivɪŋ ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd bi sɑlvd wɪð ɪnʌf tɔk. ðeɪ ʃəd tʃɹaɪ ðəɾ ɑn ə tʃɹɑlɑk sʌmtaɪm, əɹ dʒʌst ə fʊtpæd, ən si haʊ fɑɹ ðeɪ ɡɑt! wɪθaʊt ʃɛɹiəm ən ðə ɹɛst, ɹɪzɪstəns tə ɪleɪɾə wʊɾə fɔlən əpɑɹt bɪfɔɹ ɪɾ ɛvɝ hæɾ ə tʃæns tə koʊəlɛs. ɪt nɪɹli hæɾ ɛniweɪ. bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑz əz fɝmli siɾəd ɪn ðə taʊɝ əz ɛvɝ, ən æftɝ ɔl ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn θɹu, ɔl ðeɪ hæd dʌn, ɪt sim ðəɾ ivən æneɪjə sɔ ɪɾ ɔl mɛltɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə dɪzæstɝ. noʊ! dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾənd əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən sæɾ ɪɹɛkt ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. ʃi wɑz ðə lɔfəl æmɪɝlɪn, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə hɔl hæd θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ wən ðeɪ ɹeɪz hɝ, ən ʃi hæd tə kip ðə ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə əlaɪv tə hæv ɛni hoʊp ə hilɪŋ ðə taʊɝ. ɪf ðət ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə pɹitɛns ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz, ɪt wəd nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd pɹitɛndəd tə eɪm ət wʌn θɪŋ waɪl tɑɹɡəɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə kip ðə ɹɪbɛljən əlaɪv ən pʊl ɪleɪɾə daʊn, ʃi wəd du. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd.

Beonin was apparently the only one who had opposed that decision - at least, until it became apparent the others were going ahead anyway - but she drew a shuddering breath, too, and a tightness settled around her eyes. In her case, the sudden realization of just what she had undertaken might have played its part, too. Just finding someone in the Tower who was willing to talk might prove a daunting task. Eyes-and-ears inside Tar Valon could offer only hearsay about events inside the Tower; news of the Tower itself came only in dribs and drabs, from sisters venturing into Tel'aran'rhiod to glimpse fleeting reflections of the waking world, but every last one of those scraps told of Elaida ruling by edict and caprice, with not even the Hall daring to stand against her. Beonin's face took on a grayish tinge, till she began to appear more sickly than Nisao. Anaiya and the others looked as bleak as death. A wave of gloom rose in Egwene. These were among the strongest against Elaida, even the foot-dragging Beonin, who always wanted to talk rather than act. Well, Grays were noted for believing that anything could be solved with enough talk. They should try that on a Trolloc sometime, or just a footpad, and see how far they got! Without Sheriam and the rest, resistance to Elaida would have fallen apart before it ever had a chance to coalesce. It nearly had anyway. But Elaida was as firmly seated in the Tower as ever, and after all they had gone through, all they had done, it seemed that even Anaiya saw it all melting away into disaster. No! Drawing a deep breath, Egwene straightened her shoulders and sat erect in her saddle. She was the lawful Amyrlin, no matter what the Hall had thought they were getting when they raised her, and she had to keep the rebellion against Elaida alive to have any hope of healing the Tower. If that required a pretense of negotiations, it would not be the first time Aes Sedai had pretended to aim at one thing while targeting another. Whatever was required to keep the rebellion alive and pull Elaida down, she would do. Whatever was required.

"stʃɹɛtʃ ðə tɔks aʊɾ əz lɔŋ əz jə kæn," ʃi toʊl bioʊnɪn. "ju kən tɔk əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə kip ðə sikɹəts ðət nid kipɪŋ, bʌɾ əɡɹi tə nʌθɪŋ, ən kip əm tɔkɪŋ." sweɪɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ðə ɡɹeɪ dɛfənətli lʊk sɪkɝ ðən æneɪjə. ʃi ɔlmoʊst əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə ɛmpti hɝ stʌmək.

"Stretch the talks out as long as you can," she told Beonin. "You can talk about anything, so long as you keep the secrets that need keeping, but agree to nothing, and keep them talking." Swaying in her saddle, the Gray definitely looked sicker than Anaiya. She almost appeared ready to empty her stomach.

wən ðə kæmp keɪm ɪndə saɪt, wɪð ðə sʌn nɪɹli hæfweɪ tə ɪts nundeɪ pik, ði ɛskɔɹɾ ə laɪtli ɑɹmɝd hɔɹsmən bɹoʊk əweɪ bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ, livɪŋ ɛɡwin ən ðə sɪstɝz tə ɹaɪd ðə læs maɪl əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ fɑloʊd baɪ ðə wɔɹɾɝz. lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ pɔzd əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə spik wɪð əɹ wʌns mɔɹ, bʌt faɪnəli hi tɝn ɪz beɪ ist æftɝ ðə kævəlɹi, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌp əz ðeɪ vænɪʃt bɪɑn ə lɔŋ, kɑpaɪst stæn ə tʃɹiz. hi wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ dɪsəɡɹimənt, əɹ ðɛɹ dɪskʌʃənz, wɛɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd hɪɹ, ən i bɪliv ðət bioʊnɪn ən ði ʌðɝz dʒʌst wʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls θɔt ðɛm, ði ədʒəz' wɑtʃdɔɡz. ʃi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl sæɾ ət hoʊldɪŋ θɪŋz bæk fɹəm hɪm, bʌt ðə fjuɝ u nu ə sikɹət, ðə mɔɹ laɪkli ɪt wəd ɹɪmeɪn sikɹət. ðə kæmp wɑz ə spɹɔl ə tɛns ɪn ɛvɹi ʃeɪp ən saɪz ən kʌlɝ ən steɪɾ ə ɹɪpɛɹ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs kʌvɝɾ ə bɹɔd tʃɹi-ɹɪm pæstʃɝ, hæfweɪ bɪtwin tɑɹ vəlɑn ən dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt, ɪnsaɪɾ ə ɹɪŋ ə hɔɹslaɪnz ən ɹoʊz ʌv wæɡənz ən kɑɹts ɪn ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni ʃeɪps əz ðəɹ wɝ wæɡənz ən kɑɹts. tʃɪmni smoʊk ɹoʊz ɪn sɛvɹəl pleɪsəz ə fju maɪlz bɪɑn ðə tʃɹilaɪn, bʌt ðə loʊkəl fɑɹmɝz steɪɾ əweɪ ɪksɛp fəɹ sɛlɪŋ ɛɡz ən mɪlk ən bʌɾɝ, əɹ səmtaɪmz wən wʌn niɾəd hilɪŋ fɹəm səm æksəɾənt, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn əɾ ɔl ə ði ɑɹmi ɛɡwin hæd bɹɔt soʊ fɑɹ. ɡɛɹɪθ hæd kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɪz fɔɹsɪz əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ, pɑɹɾ ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊnz ɑn boʊθ bæŋks ən ðə ɹɛst ɪn wʌɾ i kɔld ɹɪzɝv kæmps, pleɪst wɛɹ mɛn kəd bi ɹʌʃt tə hɛlp faɪɾ ɔf ɛni sɔɹɾi ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs i wɑz ɹɔŋ əbaʊt haɪ kæptən tʃʌbn. ɔlweɪz kənsɪɾɝ ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi jəɹ əsʌmpʃənz ɑɹ ɹɔŋ, hi hæd toʊl hɝ. noʊ wʌn əbdʒɛktəd tə hɪz pleɪsməns, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑɾ ɪn dʒɛnɝəl ɛniweɪ. ɛni nʌmbɝ ə sɪstɝz wɝ ɹɛɾi tə nɪtpɪk ðə dɪteɪlz, bʌt hoʊldɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊnz wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ tə bɪsidʒ tɑɹ vəlɑn, æftɝ ɔl. baɪ lænd, ɪt wɑz. ən ə ɡʊd mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ pliz tə hæv ðə soʊlʒɝz aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɪf nɑɾ aʊɾ ə maɪnd.

When the camp came into sight, with the sun nearly halfway to its noonday peak, the escort of lightly armored horsemen broke away back toward the river, leaving Egwene and the sisters to ride the last mile across the snow followed by the Warders. Lord Gareth paused as if he wanted to speak with her once more, but finally he turned his bay east after the cavalry, trotting to catch up as they vanished beyond a long, coppiced stand of trees. He would not bring up their disagreement, or their discussions, where anyone else could hear, and he believed that Beonin and the others just what everyone else thought them, the Ajahs' watchdogs. She felt a little sad at holding things back from him, but the fewer who knew a secret, the more likely it would remain secret. The camp was a sprawl of tents in every shape and size and color and state of repair that almost covered a broad tree-rimmed pasture, halfway between Tar Valon and Dragonmount, inside a ring of horselines and rows of wagons and carts in almost as many shapes as there were wagons and carts. Chimney smoke rose in several places a few miles beyond the treeline, but the local farmers stayed away except for selling eggs and milk and butter, or sometimes when one needed Healing from some accident, and there was no sign at all of the army Egwene had brought so far. Gareth had concentrated his forces along the river, part occupying the bridge towns on both banks and the rest in what he called reserve camps, placed where men could be rushed to help fight off any sortie in strength from the city, just in case he was wrong about High Captain Chubain. Always consider the possibility your assumptions are wrong, he had told her. No one objected to his placements, of course, not in general anyway. Any number of sisters were ready to nitpick the details, but holding the bridge towns was the only way to besiege Tar Valon, after all. By land, it was. And a good many Aes Sedai were pleased to have the soldiers out of sight if not out of mind.

θɹi wɔɹɾɝz ɪn kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks keɪm ɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə kæmp əz ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz əpɹoʊtʃt, wʌn ə ðɛm vɛɹi tɔl ən wʌn kwaɪt ʃɔɹt, soʊ ðeɪ simd ɝeɪnʒd ɪn stɛps. meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ baʊz tə ɛɡwin ən ðə sɪstɝz, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə wɔɹɾɝz bɪhaɪnd, ðeɪ ɔl hæd ðət deɪnʒɝəs lʊk ə mɛn soʊ kɑnfəɾənt ðət ðeɪ hæd noʊ nid tə kənvɪns ɛniwʌn haʊ deɪnʒɝəs ðeɪ wɝ, wɪtʃ sʌmhaʊ meɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɛvəɾənt. eɪ wɔɹɾɝ əɾ ɪz iz ən ə laɪən ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ə hɪl, soʊ wɛn ən oʊl seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪt wɑz lɔst ɪn ðə jɪɹz, bʌt ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ mɔɹ. ðə sɪstɝz wɝ nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli kəmpleɪsən əbaʊt ðə seɪfti ʌv ivən ə kæmp fʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz.

Three Warders in color-shifting cloaks came riding out from the camp as Egwene and the others approached, one of them very tall and one quite short, so they seemed arranged in steps. Making their bows to Egwene and the sisters, nodding to the Warders behind, they all had that dangerous look of men so confident that they had no need to convince anyone how dangerous they were, which somehow made it all the more evident. A Warder at his ease and a lion resting on a hill, so went an old saying among Aes Sedai. The rest of it was lost in the years, but there really was no need to say more.
