The sisters were not entirely complacent about the safety of even a camp full of Aes Sedai, under the circumstances.

wɔɹɾɝz pətʃɹoʊl kloʊsli fəɹ maɪlz ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, laɪənz ɑn ðə pɹaʊl. æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝz, ɔl bʌt ʃɛɹiəm, skæɾɝd əz sun əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɝst ɹoʊ ʌv tɛns bɪɑn ðə wæɡənz. itʃ wəd bi sikɪŋ aʊt ðə hɛɾ ə hɝ ədʒɑ, ɑstɛnsəbli tə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn ɛɡwinz*  ɛs i si ɑɹ i ti ɛs fɔɹhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntin ɹaɪd tə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪð lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ, ən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðoʊz ədʒɑ hɛdz nu ðət səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz wɪð ɪleɪɾə ən ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz biɪŋ fɝm. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn iziɝ ɪf ʃi nu hu ðoʊz wɪmən wɝ, bʌɾ ivən oʊðz ə fiəlti dɪd nɑt stʃɹɛtʃ tə ɹɪvilɪŋ ðæt. maɪɹɛl hæd nɪɹli swɑloʊɾ əɹ tʌŋ wən ɛɡwin sədʒɛstəɾ ɪt. biɪŋ dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ə dʒɑb wɪθaʊt tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɑz hɑɹdli ðə bɛst weɪ tə lɝn ɪt, ən ɛɡwin nu ʃi hæɾ oʊʃənz tə lɝn jɛɾ əbaʊt biɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn.

Warders patrolled closely for miles in every direction, lions on the prowl. Anaiya and the others, all but Sheriam, scattered as soon as they reached the first row of tents beyond the wagons. Each would be seeking out the head of her Ajah, ostensibly to report on Egwene's*  S E C R E T S 417 ride to the river with Lord Gareth, and more importantly, to make sure those Ajah heads knew that some of the Sitters were talking about negotiations with Elaida and that Egwene was being firm. It would have been easier if she knew who those women were, but even oaths of fealty did not stretch to revealing that. Myrelle had nearly swallowed her tongue when Egwene suggested it. Being dropped into a job without training was hardly the best way to learn it, and Egwene knew she had oceans to learn yet about being Amyrlin.

oʊʃənz tə lɝn, ən ə dʒɑb ʌv wɝk tə də ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "ɪf jəl fɝɡɪv mi, mʌðɝ," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd wən bioʊnɪn, ðə læs tə ɡoʊ, vænɪʃt əmʌŋ ðə tɛns tʃɹeɪl baɪ hɝ skɑɹ-feɪst wɔɹɾɝ, "aɪ hæv ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl paɪl haɪ wɪð peɪpɝ." ðə læk ʌv ɪnθuziæzəm ɪn əɹ vɔɪs wɑz ʌndɝstændəbəl. ðə kipɝz stoʊl keɪm əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɝ-ɡɹoʊɪŋ stæks ə ɹɪpɔɹts tə bi sɔɹɾɪd ən dɑkjəməns tə bi pɹipɛɹd. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ zil fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dʒɑb, wɪtʃ ɪn ðɪs keɪs wɑz tə kip ðə kæmp ɹʌnɪŋ, ʃɛɹiəm hæd bɪn hɝd tə mʌɾɝ fɝvənt wɪʃɪz, wən kənfɹʌntəd baɪ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ maʊn ə peɪpɝz, ðət ʃi wɑz stɪl mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. stɪl, əz sun əz ɛɡwin ɡeɪv pɝmɪʃən, ʃi buɾɪd əɹ blækfʊɾɪd dæpəl tə ə tʃɹɑt, skæɾɝɪŋ ə kʌvi ʌv wɝkmɪn ɪn ɹʌf koʊts ən mʌflɝz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz, hu wɝ kæɹiɪŋ lɑɹdʒ bæskəts ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. wʌn fɛl flæɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs ɪn ðə hæfɹəzən mʌk ðət pæs fəɹ ə stʃɹit. ʃɛɹiəmz ɑɹɪnvɑɹ, ə slɪm kɛɹhinɪn wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ tɛmpəlz, pɔz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə fɛloʊ wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪz fit, ðən spɝɾ ɪz dɑɹk beɪ stæljən æftɝ hɝ, livɪŋ ðə wɝkmən tə hɪz kɝsɪz, moʊst ʌv wɪtʃ sim tə bi dɝɛktəɾ əɾ ɪz kəmpænjənz' læftɝ. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ, jə ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ.

Oceans to learn, and a job of work to do at the same time. "If you will forgive me, Mother," Sheriam said when Beonin, the last to go, vanished among the tents trailed by her scar-faced Warder, "I have a writing table piled high with paper." The lack of enthusiasm in her voice was understandable. The Keeper's stole came along with ever-growing stacks of reports to be sorted and documents to be prepared. Despite her zeal for the rest of the job, which in this case was to keep the camp running, Sheriam had been heard to mutter fervent wishes, when confronted by yet another mound of papers, that she was still Mistress of Novices. Still, as soon as Egwene gave permission, she booted her blackfooted dapple to a trot, scattering a covey of workmen in rough coats and mufflers wrapped around their heads, who were carrying large baskets on their backs. One fell flat on his face in the halffrozen muck that passed for a street. Sheriam's Arinvar, a slim Cairhienin with graying temples, paused long enough to make sure the fellow was getting to his feet, then spurred his dark bay stallion after her, leaving the workman to his curses, most of which seemed to be directed at his companions' laughter. Everyone knew that when an Aes Sedai wanted to go somewhere, you got out of the way.

wʌt hæd spɪld aʊɾ ə ðə fɛloʊz bæskəɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹit kɑɾ ɛɡwinz aɪ ən meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ, ə tɔl hip ə mil kɹɔlɪŋ wɪð wivəlz tɪl ɪt sim ðəɹ wɝ əz mɛni muvɪŋ blæk spɛks əz mil. ðə mɛn mʌst ɔl əv bɪn kæɹiɪŋ ɹuən mil tə ðə mɪɾən hips. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus bɑðɝɪŋ tə sɪft ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪnfɛstəd - oʊnli sʌmwʌn u wɑz stɑɹvɪŋ kəɾ iɾ ɪt - bʌt tu mɛni bæskəts ə mil ən ɡɹeɪn hæd tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv ɛvɹi deɪ.

What had spilled out of the fellow's basket onto the street caught Egwene's eye and made her shiver, a tall heap of meal crawling with weevils till it seemed there were as many moving black specks as meal. The men must all have been carrying ruined meal to the midden heaps. There was no use bothering to sift anything that infested - only someone who was starving could eat it - but too many baskets of meal and grain had to be disposed of every day.

fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, hæf ðə bæɹəlz ə sɔl pɔɹk ən sɔl bif oʊpən fəɹ jus stæŋk soʊ ðət ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn ɪksɛp bɛɹi ðɛm. fəɹ ðə sɝvəns ən wɝkmɪn, ət lis ðoʊz u hæɾ ɪkspɪɹiəns ə kæmp laɪf, ðət wɑz nʌθɪŋ nu. ə lɪɾəl wɝs ðən juʒəwəl, bʌt nɑɾ ənhɝɾ ʌv. wivəlz kəɾ əpɪɹ ɛni taɪm, ən mɝtʃəns tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʃɹɛtʃ ðɛɹ pɹɑfəts ɔlweɪz soʊl səm ɹɑɾɪŋ miɾ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə ɡʊd. əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ, ɪt wɑz kɑz fəɹ dip wɝi. ɛvɹi bæɹəl ə mit, ɛvɹi sæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn əɹ flaʊɝ əɹ mil, hæd bɪn sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə kipɪŋ əz sun əz bɑt, ən wʌtɛvɝ wɑz woʊvən ɪndə ə kipɪŋ kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ əntɪl ðə wiv wɑz ɹimuvd. bʌt stɪl ðə mit ɹɑɾɪd ən ði ɪnsɛks mʌltəplaɪd. ɪt wɑz əz ðoʊ seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪtsɛlf wɑz feɪlɪŋ. jə kəd ɡɛɾ ə sɪstɝ tə meɪk dʒoʊks əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ bɪfɔɹ jə kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt ðæt.

For that matter, half the barrels of salt pork and salt beef opened for use stank so that there was nothing to be done except bury them. For the servants and workmen, at least those who had experience of camp life, that was nothing new. A little worse than usual, but not unheard of. Weevils could appear any time, and merchants trying to stretch their profits always sold some rotting meat along with the good. Among the Aes Sedai, though, it was cause for deep worry. Every barrel of meat, every sack of grain or flour or meal, had been surrounded by a Keeping as soon as bought, and whatever was woven into a Keeping could not change until the weave was removed. But still the meat rotted and the insects multiplied. It was as though saidar itself was failing. You could get a sister to make jokes about the Black Ajah before you could get her to talk about that.

wʌn ə ðə læfɪŋ mɛn kɑt saɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwin wɑtʃɪŋ əm ən nʌdʒ ðə mʌd-kʌvɝd fɛloʊ, hu mɑɾɝeɪtɪd ɪz læŋɡwədʒ, ðoʊ nɑt vɛɹi fɑɹ. hi ivən ɡlaʊɝɾ əz ɪf bleɪmɪŋ əɹ fəɹ ɪz fɔl. wɪð əɹ feɪs hæf-hɪɾən baɪ hɝ hʊɾ ən ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl foʊldəɾ ɪn əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ðeɪ sim tə teɪk əɹ fəɹ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, nɑɾ ɔl ə hum hæɾ ɪnʌf pɹɑpɝ kloʊðɪŋ tə ɔlweɪz dʒɹɛs əz ðeɪ ʃʊd, əɹ pɝhæps ə vɪzəɾɝ. wɪmən fɹikwənli slɪpt ɪndə ðə kæmp, ɔfən kipɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən ɪn pʌblɪk əntɪl ðeɪ lɛft əɡɛn wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɔɹ faɪn sɪlks əɹ θɹɛdbɛɹ wʊl, ən ʃoʊɪŋ ə saʊɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən tə ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ əɹ ən æksɛptɪd wɑz sɝɾənli seɪfɝ ðən ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ əɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt simd ɑd nɑt tə hæv ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt bɑbɪŋ ən boʊɪŋ. ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ðə sæɾəl sɪns bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt, ən ɪf ə hɑt bæθ wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən - wɔɾɝ hæd tə bi kæɹiɾ ɪn fɹəm ðə wɛlz ðət hæd bɪn dʌɡ hæf ə maɪl wɛst ə ðə kæmp, wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɔl bʌt ðə moʊs fæstɪɾiəs əɹ sɛlf-əbzɔɹb sɪstɝz lɪmət ðɛmsɛlvz  - ɪf ə lɔŋ hɑt soʊk wɑz nɑt tə bi hæd, ʃi stɪl wʊɾə laɪk tə pʊɾ əɹ fit bæk ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əɹ bɛɾɝ jɛt, pʊɾ əm ʌp ɑn ə fʊtstul. bɪsaɪdz, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛt ðə koʊl tʌtʃ jə wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə seɪm əz wɔɹmɪŋ jəɹ hænz əɾ ə toʊsti bɹeɪziɝ. hɝ oʊn ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl wəɾ əv ɪts paɪl ə peɪpɝ, tu. læs naɪt ʃi hæd toʊld ʃɛɹiəm tə ɡɪv əɹ ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ðə steɪɾ ʌv wæɡən ɹɪpɛɹz ən ðə səplaɪ ʌv fɑɾɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz. ðeɪ wəd bi dʒɹaɪ ən bɔɹɪŋ, bʌt ʃi tʃɛkt ɑn dɪfɹən ɛɹiəz ɛvɹi deɪ, soʊ ʃi kəɾ ət lis tɛl wɛðɝ wʌt pipəl toʊld əɹ wɑz beɪst ɑn fækt əɹ wɪʃɪz. ən ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ði aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz' ɹɪpɔɹts.

One of the laughing men caught sight of Egwene watching them and nudged the mud-covered fellow, who moderated his language, though not very far. He even glowered as if blaming her for his fall. With her face half-hidden by her hood and the Amyrlin's stole folded in her belt pouch, they seemed to take her for one of the Accepted, not all of whom had enough proper clothing to always dress as they should, or perhaps a visitor. Women frequently slipped into the camp, often keeping their faces hidden in public until they left again whether they wore fine silks or threadbare wool, and showing a sour expression to a stranger or an Accepted was certainly safer than grimacing at an Aes Sedai. It seemed odd not to have everyone in sight bobbing and bowing. She had been in the saddle since before first light, and if a hot bath was out of the question - water had to be carried in from the wells that had been dug half a mile west of the camp, which made all but the most fastidious or self-absorbed sisters limit themselves  - if a long hot soak was not to be had, she still would have liked to put her feet back on the ground. Or better yet, put them up on a footstool. Besides, refusing to let the cold touch you was not at all the same as warming your hands at a toasty brazier. Her own writing table would have its pile of paper, too. Last night she had told Sheriam to give her the reports on the state of wagon repairs and the supply of fodder for the horses. They would be dry and boring, but she checked on different areas every day, so she could at least tell whether what people told her was based on fact or wishes. And there were always the eyes-and-ears' reports.

ði ədʒəz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pæs əlɔŋ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit meɪd fəɹ fæsəneɪɾɪŋ ɹɛɾɪŋ wən kəmpɛɹd tə wʌt sɪuən ən lin ɡeɪv əɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ eɪdʒəns. ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ ðət ðəɹ wɝ kɑntʃɹədɪkʃənz, jɛt wʌt ði ədʒəz tʃoʊz tə kip tə ðɛmsɛlvz kəd dʒɹɔ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ pɪktʃɝz. kʌmfɝɾ ən duɾi boʊθ pʊld əɹ təwɔɹɾ əɹ stʌɾi - dʒʌst ənʌðɝ tɛnt, ɹɪli, ðoʊ ɛvɹiwʌn kɔld ɪt ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi - bʌt ðɪs wɑz ən ɑpɝtunəɾi tə lʊk ɝaʊnd wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ heɪstəli meɪd ɹɛɾi əhɛɾ ə hɝ ɝaɪvəl. pʊlɪŋ əɹ hʊɾ ə lɪɾəl fɝðɝ fɔɹwɝd tə bɛɾɝ kənsil əɹ feɪs, ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ hilz laɪtli tə deɪʃɝz flæŋks. ðəɹ wɝ fju pipəl maʊntəd, moʊsli wɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ ði ɪnfɹikwənt ɡɹum æɾəd tə ðə tʃɹæfɪk, liɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs əɾ əz kloʊs tə ə tʃɹɑɾ əz kəd bi mænədʒd ɪn ði æŋkəl-dip slʌʃ, bʌt noʊ wʌn sim tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ əɹ əɹ maʊnt. ɪn kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə nɪɹli ɛmpti stʃɹits, ðə wʊɾən wɔkweɪz, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɹʌf plæŋks pɛɡd ətɑp sɔn lɔɡz, ʃɪftəd slaɪtli ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ə pipəl. ðə hændfʊl ə mɛn, dɑɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹimz ʌv wɪmən laɪk ɹeɪzənz ɪn ə tʃip keɪk, wɔk twaɪs əz fæst əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. ɛksɛptɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz, mɛn ɡɑt ðɛɹ bɪznəs əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ dʌn əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl. nɪɹli ɔl ðə wɪmən hæd ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən, ðɛɹ bɹɛθ mɪstɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpənɪŋz ə ðɛɹ hʊdz, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz izi tə pɪk aʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm vɪzəɾɝz wɛðɝ ðɛɹ kloʊks wɝ pleɪn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ən laɪnd wɪð fɝ. ðə kɹaʊdz pɑɹɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə sɪstɝ. ɛniwʌn ɛls hæd tə wiv əɹ weɪ θɹu. nɑt ðət mɛni sɪstɝz wɝ əbaʊɾ ɑn ðɪs fɹɪdʒəd mɪdmɔɹnɪŋ. moʊst wəd bi snʌɡ ɪn ðɛɹ tɛns. əloʊn əɹ ɪn tuz əɹ θɹiz, ðeɪ wəd bi ɹiɾɪŋ, əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ lɛɾɝz, əɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ ðɛɹ vɪzəɾɝz əbaʊt wʌtɛvɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðoʊz wɪmən hæd bɹɔt. wɪtʃ maɪɾ əɹ maɪt nɑt bi ʃɛɹd wɪð ðə ɹɛst ʌv ə sɪstɝz ədʒɑ, mʌtʃ lɛs wɪð ɛniwʌn ɛls. ðə wɝl sɔ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ə mɑnəlɪθ, taʊɝɪŋ ən sɑləd, əɹ ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ ðə kɝən dɪvɪʒən ɪn ðə taʊɝ bɪkeɪm kɑmən nɑlədʒ, jɛt ðə pjʊɹ fækt wɑz ðət ði ədʒəz stʊɾ əpɑɹɾ ɪn ɔl bʌt neɪm, ðə hɔl ðɛɹ oʊnli tʃɹu miɾɪŋ pɔɪnt, ən ðə sɪstɝz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə kɑnvəkeɪʃən ə hɝməts, spikɪŋ θɹi wɝdz bɪɑnd wʌt wɑz æbsəlutli ɹikwaɪɝɾ oʊnli wɪð ə fju fɹɛnz. əɹ wɪð ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ ðeɪ hæd dʒɔɪn ɪn səm dɪzaɪn.

The Ajahs decided to pass along to the Amyrlin Seat made for fascinating reading when compared to what Siuan and Leane gave her from their agents. It was not so much that there were contradictions, yet what the Ajahs chose to keep to themselves could draw interesting pictures. Comfort and duty both pulled her toward her study - just another tent, really, though everyone called it the Amyrlin's study - but this was an opportunity to look around without having everything hastily made ready ahead of her arrival. Pulling her hood a little further forward to better conceal her face, she touched her heels lightly to Daishar's flanks. There were few people mounted, mostly Warders, though the infrequent groom added to the traffic, leading a horse at as close to a trot as could be managed in the ankle-deep slush, but no one seemed to recognize her or her mount. In contrast to the nearly empty streets, the wooden walkways, no more than rough planks pegged atop sawn logs, shifted slightly under the weight of people. The handful of men, dotting the streams of women like raisins in a cheap cake, walked twice as fast as anyone else. Excepting Warders, men got their business among Aes Sedai done as quickly as possible. Nearly all the women had their faces hidden, their breath misting in the openings of their hoods, yet it was easy to pick out Aes Sedai from visitors whether their cloaks were plain or embroidered and lined with fur. The crowds parted in front of a sister. Anyone else had to weave her way through. Not that many sisters were about on this frigid midmorning. Most would be snug in their tents. Alone or in twos or threes, they would be reading, or writing letters, or questioning their visitors about whatever information those women had brought. Which might or might not be shared with the rest of a sister's Ajah, much less with anyone else. The world saw Aes Sedai as a monolith, towering and solid, or it had before the current division in the Tower became common knowledge, yet the pure fact was that the Ajahs stood apart in all but name, the Hall their only true meeting point, and the sisters themselves were little more than a convocation of hermits, speaking three words beyond what was absolutely required only with a few friends. Or with another sister they had joined in some design.

wʌtɛvɝ ɛls tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊt ðə taʊɝ, ɛɡwin wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət nɛvɝ wʊd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn pɹitɛndɪŋ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ɛvɝ wəd bi, ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪvɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ ɔnwɝd, ɔl ɪts paʊɝfəl kɝəns hɪɾən dip, ɔltɝɪŋ ɪts kɔɹs wɪð ɪmpɝsɛptɪbəl sloʊnəs. ʃi hæd bɪlt ə fju heɪsti dæmz ɪn ðət ɹɪvɝ, daɪvɝɾɪŋ ə stʃɹim hɪɹ ən ə stʃɹim ðəɹ fəɹ əɹ oʊn pɝpəsəz, jɛt ʃi nu ðeɪ wɝ tɛmpɝɛɹi stʃɹʌktʃɝz. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðoʊz dip kɝəns wəɾ ʌndɝkʌɾ əɹ dæmz.

Whatever else changed about the Tower, Egwene was sure that never would. There was no point pretending that Aes Sedai had ever been anything but Aes Sedai or ever would be, a great river rolling onward, all its powerful currents hidden deep, altering its course with imperceptible slowness. She had built a few hasty dams in that river, diverting a stream here and a stream there for her own purposes, yet she knew they were temporary structures. Sooner or later those deep currents would undercut her dams.

ʃi kəɾ oʊnli pɹeɪ ðeɪ læstəd lɔŋ ɪnʌf. pɹeɪ, ən ʃɔɹ ʌp əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. vɛɹi əkeɪʒənəli wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə θɹɔŋ, wɪð ðə sɛvən bænz ə kʌlɝ ɑn ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ waɪt kloʊk, bʌt moʊs baɪ fɑɹ wɝ nɑvəsɪz ɪn ʌnədɔɹnd waɪt wʊl. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə ðə twɛnti-wʌn æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə kæmp æktʃəli  pəzɛs bændɪd kloʊks, ən ðeɪ seɪv ðɛɹ fju bændɪd dʒɹɛsəz fəɹ titʃɪŋ klæsəz əɹ ətɛndɪŋ sɪstɝz, jɛt ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝts hæd bɪn meɪd tə si ðəɾ ɛvɹi nɑvəs wɑz dʒɹɛst ɪn waɪɾ əɾ ɔl taɪmz, ivən ɪf ʃi oʊnli hæd wʌn tʃeɪnʒ. ði æksɛptɪɾ ɪnɛvəɾəbli tʃɹaɪd tə muv wɪð ðə swɑnlaɪk ɡlaɪɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən wʌn əɹ tu nɪɹli mænədʒ dɪspaɪt ðə tɪltɪŋ ə ðə wɔkweɪz ʌndɝfʊt, bʌt ðə nɑvəsɪz dɑɹɾɪd əlɔŋ ɔlmoʊst əz kwɪkli əz ðə fju mɛn, skɝiɪŋ ɑn ɛɹənz əɹ hɝiɪŋ tə klæsəz ɪn ɡɹups ə sɪks əɹ sɛvən.

She could only pray they lasted long enough. Pray, and shore up as hard as she could. Very occasionally one of the Accepted appeared in the throng, with the seven bands of color on the hood of her white cloak, but most by far were novices in unadorned white wool. Only a handful of the twenty-one Accepted in the camp actually possessed banded cloaks, and they saved their few banded dresses for teaching classes or attending sisters, yet great efforts had been made to see that every novice was dressed in white at all times, even if she only had one change. The Accepted inevitably tried to move with the swanlike glide of Aes Sedai, and one or two nearly managed despite the tilting of the walkways underfoot, but the novices darted along almost as quickly as the few men, scurrying on errands or hurrying to classes in groups of six or seven.

ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt hæd soʊ mɛni nɑvəsɪz tə titʃ ɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm, nɑt sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wən ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɛni mɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛl, ən ðə ɹɪzʌlt ə faɪndɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz wɪð nɪɹ ə θaʊzən stuɾənts hæd bɪn ʌɾɝ kənfjuʒən əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɔɹɡənaɪzd ɪndə ðiz "fæmliz." ðə neɪm wɑz nɑt stʃɹɪkli əfɪʃəl, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz juzd ivən baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu stɪl dɪslaɪk teɪkɪŋ ɛni wʊmən u æskt. naʊ ɛvɹi nɑvəs nu wɛɹ ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ən wɛn, ən ɛvɹi sɪstɝ kəɾ ət lis faɪn aʊt. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðət ðə nʌmbɝ ə ɹʌnəweɪz hæd dɪklaɪnd. ðət wɑz ɔlweɪz ə kənsɝn fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən sɛvɹəl hʌnʒɹəd ə ðiz wɪmən maɪt wɛl əteɪn ðə ʃɔl. noʊ sɪstɝ wɑntəd tə luz wʌn ə ðoʊz, əɹ ɛni, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, nɑt bɪfɔɹ ðə dɪsɪʒən wɑz meɪd tə sɛn ə wʊmən əweɪ. wɪmən stɪl slɪpt ɔf əkeɪʒənəli æftɝ ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ wɑz hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ðə ɹoʊd tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪz ʃɔl lɔŋɡɝ, bʌt kwaɪɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə fæmliz meɪkɪŋ ɪɾ iziɝ tə kip tʃɹæk, ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ sim tə bi lɛs ətʃɹæktɪv tə wɪmən u hæd faɪv əɹ sɪks kʌzənz, əz ðeɪ wɝ kɔld, tə lin ɑn.

Aes Sedai had not had so many novices to teach in a very long time, not since before the Trolloc Wars, when there had been many more Aes Sedai as well, and the result of finding themselves with near a thousand students had been utter confusion until they were organized into these "families." The name was not strictly official, yet it was used even by Aes Sedai who still disliked taking any woman who asked. Now every novice knew where she was supposed to be and when, and every sister could at least find out. Not to mention that the number of runaways had declined. That was always a concern for Aes Sedai, and several hundred of these women might well attain the shawl. No sister wanted to lose one of those, or any, for that matter, not before the decision was made to send a woman away. Women still slipped off occasionally after realizing that the training was harder than they had expected and the road to an Aes Sedai's shawl longer, but quite apart from the families making it easier to keep track, running away seemed to be less attractive to women who had five or six cousins, as they were called, to lean on.

wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə bɪɡ skwɛɹ pəvɪljən ðət sɝvd əz ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ʃi tɝn deɪʃɝ daʊn ə saɪd stʃɹit. ðə wɔkweɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə peɪl bɹaʊn kænvəs pəvɪljən wɑz ɛmpti  -  ðə hɔl wɑz nɑɾ ə pleɪs ɛniwʌn əpɹoʊtʃt wɪθaʊt bɪznəs ðɛɹ  -  bʌt ðə mʌtʃ-pætʃt saɪd kɝɾənz wɝ kɛp daʊn wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹizən tə meɪk ðə wɝkɪŋz ə ðə hɔl pʌblɪk, soʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tɛlɪŋ u maɪt stɛp aʊt. ɛni sɪɾɝ wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz deɪʃɝ əɾ ə ɡlæns, ən səm sɪɾɝz ʃi wəɾ əz sun əvɔɪɾ ivən mɔɹ ðən ʌðɝz. ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, hu ɹɪzɪstɪɾ əɹ əθɔɹəɾi əz ɪnstɪŋktɪvli əz ðeɪ əpoʊzd itʃ ʌðɝ. əɹ ɛni ʌv ðoʊz u hæd bɪɡʌn tɔkɪŋ ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə bɪliv ðət ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs hoʊpɪŋ tə ɹæli spɪɹəts, əɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv kɛp tə wɪspɝz. ðə kɝɾəsiz hæd tə bi meɪnteɪnd, ðoʊ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd bɑks sʌmwʌnz ɪɹz, jɛt noʊ wʌn kəd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz biɪŋ snʌbd ɪf ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt si hɝ. ə feɪn sɪlvɝi laɪt flæʃt bɪhaɪn ə tɔl kænvəs wɔl dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə hɝ, sɝaʊndɪŋ wʌn ə ðə kæmps tu tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz, ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ tu sɪstɝz ɪmɝdʒ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd wʌn ə ðə flæps. niðɝ fidʒɹɪn nɔɹ ʃɛmɑɹi wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə wiv ə ɡeɪtweɪ baɪ hɝsɛlf, bʌt lɪŋkt ʃi θɔt ðeɪ kəd dʒʌs mænədʒ wʌn bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə wɔk θɹu. hɛdz kloʊs təɡɛðɝ ɪn dip kɑnvɝseɪʃən, stʃɹeɪnʒli ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌs pɪnɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks.

Well short of the big square pavilion that served as the Hall of the Tower, she turned Daishar down a side street. The walkway in front of the pale brown canvas pavilion was empty  -  the Hall was not a place anyone approached without business there  -  but the much-patched side curtains were kept down without a reason to make the workings of the Hall public, so there was no telling who might step out. Any Sitter would recognize Daishar at a glance, and some Sitters she would as soon avoid even more than others. Lelaine and Romanda, for example, who resisted her authority as instinctively as they opposed each other. Or any of those who had begun talking of negotiations. It was too much to believe that they were just hoping to rally spirits, or they would not have kept to whispers. The courtesies had to be maintained, though, no matter how often she wished she could box someone's ears, yet no one could think she was being snubbed if Egwene did not see her. A faint silvery light flashed behind a tall canvas wall just ahead of her, surrounding one of the camp's two Traveling grounds, and a moment later two sisters emerged from behind one of the flaps. Neither Phaedrine nor Shemari was strong enough to weave a gateway by herself, but linked she thought they could just manage one big enough to walk through. Heads close together in deep conversation, strangely they were just pinning on their cloaks.

ɛɡwin kɛpt əɹ feɪs əvɝɾəd ɛniweɪ əz ʃi ɹoʊd baɪ. boʊθ ə ðə bɹaʊnz hæd tɔɾ əɹ əz ə nɑvəs, ən fidʒɹɪn stɪl sim sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. lin əz ə hɛɹən, ʃi wɑz kwaɪt keɪpəbəl ʌv weɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə mʌk tə æsk wɛðɝ ɛɡwin niɾəd əsɪstəns. ʃɛmɑɹi, ə vɪɡɝəs skwɹəfeɪst wʊmən u lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ə ɡɹin ðən ə laɪbɹɛɹiən, wɑz ɔlweɪz bɪɑn pɹɑpɝ ɪn əɹ bɪheɪvjɝ.

Egwene kept her face averted anyway as she rode by. Both of the Browns had taught her as a novice, and Phaedrine still seemed surprised that Egwene was Amyrlin. Lean as a heron, she was quite capable of wading out into the muck to ask whether Egwene needed assistance. Shemari, a vigorous squarefaced woman who looked more like a Green than a librarian, was always beyond proper in her behavior.

mʌtʃ bɪɑnd. hɝ dip kɝtsiz, suɾəbəl fəɹ ə nɑvəs, kæɹiɾ ət list ə sədʒɛstʃən ə mɑkɝi noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ smuð əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən, nɑt lis kəz ʃi hæd bɪn noʊn tə kɝtsi wən ʃi sɔ ɛɡwin ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əweɪ.

Much beyond. Her deep curtsies, suitable for a novice, carried at least a suggestion of mockery no matter how smooth her expression, not least because she had been known to curtsy when she saw Egwene a hundred paces away.

wɛɹ hæd ðeɪ bɪn, ʃi wʌndɝd. sʌmwɛɹ ɪndɔɹz, pɝhæps, əɹ ət list wɔɹmɝ ðən ðə kæmp. noʊ wʌn ɹɪli kɛp tʃɹæk ə ðə sɪstɝz' kʌmɪŋz ən ɡoʊɪŋz, ʌv kɔɹs, nɑɾ ivən ði ədʒəz. kʌstəm ɹuld ɛvɹiwʌn, ən kʌstəm stʃɹɔŋli dɪskɝədʒ dɝɛkt kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt wʌɾ ə sɪstɝ wɑz duɪŋ əɹ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ. moʊs laɪkli, fidʒɹɪn ən ʃɛmɑɹi hæd bɪn tə hɪɹ fɹəm səm ə ðɛɹ aɪz-ændɪɹz feɪs tə feɪs. əɹ meɪbi tə lʊk əɾ ə bʊk ɪn səm laɪbɹɛɹi. ðeɪ wɝ bɹaʊn. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp θɪŋkɪŋ ə naɪsaʊz kɑmɛn əbaʊt sɪstɝz slɪpɪŋ əweɪ tə ɪleɪɾə. ɪt wɑz kwaɪt pɑsəbəl tə haɪɝ ə boʊtmən tə meɪk ðə kɹɔsɪŋ tə ðə sɪɾi, wɛɹ dʌzənz ə taɪni wɔɾɝ ɡeɪts ɡeɪv ɛntʃɹəns tə ɛniwʌn u wɪʃt ɪt, bʌt wɪð ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə ɹɪsk ɪkspoʊʒɝ baɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɹɪvɝ ən æskɪŋ æftɝ boʊts. dʒʌst wʌn sɪstɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ wɪð ðə nɑlədʒ ə ðət wiv wəd ɡɪv əweɪ ðɛɹ lɑɹdʒəst ædvæntɪdʒ. ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə stɑp ɪt. ɪksɛp tə kip hɑɹɾ ɪn ði ɑpəzɪʃən tə ɪleɪɾə.

Where had they been, she wondered. Somewhere indoors, perhaps, or at least warmer than the camp. No one really kept track of the sisters' comings and goings, of course, not even the Ajahs. Custom ruled everyone, and custom strongly discouraged direct questions about what a sister was doing or where she was going. Most likely, Phaedrine and Shemari had been to hear from some of their eyes-andears face to face. Or maybe to look at a book in some library. They were Brown. But she could not help thinking of Nisao's comment about sisters slipping away to Elaida. It was quite possible to hire a boatman to make the crossing to the city, where dozens of tiny water gates gave entrance to anyone who wished it, but with a gateway, there was no need to risk exposure by riding to the river and asking after boats. Just one sister returning to the Tower with the knowledge of that weave would give away their largest advantage. And there was no way to stop it. Except to keep heart in the opposition to Elaida.

ɪksɛp tə meɪk ðə sɪstɝz bɪliv ðəɹ kəd bi ə kwɪk ɛn tə ðɪs. ɪf oʊnli ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə ə kwɪk ɛnd.

Except to make the sisters believe there could be a quick end to this. If only there was a way to a quick end.

nɑt fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd, ɛɡwin dʒɹu ɹeɪn ən fɹaʊn əɾ ə lɔŋ wɔl-tɛnt, ivən mɔɹ pætʃt ðən ðə hɔl. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm swɑnɪŋ daʊn ðə wɔkweɪ - ʃi wɔɹ ə pleɪn dɑɹk blu kloʊk, ən ðə kaʊl hɪɾ əɹ feɪs, bʌt nɑvəsɪz ən ʌðɝz skɪpt aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ əz ðeɪ nɛvɝ wəɾ əv fəɹ ə mɝtʃənt, seɪ - ən pɔzd ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛnt, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən bɪfɔɹ pʊʃɪŋ əsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹi flæp tə ɡoʊ ɪnsaɪd, hɝ ənwɪlɪŋnɪs əz klɪɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæd ʃaʊɾəd. ɛɡwin hæd nɛvɝ ɡɔn ɪn ðɛɹ. ʃi kəd fil seɪaɪdɑɹ biɪŋ tʃænəld ɪnsaɪd, ðoʊ feɪnli. ði əmaʊnt nɛsəsɛɹi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli smɔl. ə kwɪk vɪzət fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn ʃəd nɑt dʒɹɔ tu mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən, haʊɛvɝ.

Not far beyond the Traveling ground, Egwene drew rein and frowned at a long wall-tent, even more patched than the Hall. An Aes Sedai came swanning down the walkway - she wore a plain dark blue cloak, and the cowl hid her face, but novices and others skipped out of her way as they never would have for a merchant, say - and paused in front of the tent, looking at it for a long moment before pushing aside the entry flap to go inside, her unwillingness as clear as if she had shouted. Egwene had never gone in there. She could feel saidar being channeled inside, though faintly. The amount necessary was surprisingly small. A quick visit from the Amyrlin should not draw too much attention, however.

ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑntəd tə si wʌt ʃi hæd sɛɾ ɪn moʊʃən. dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɛnt, ðoʊ, ʃi dɪskʌvɝɾ ə tʃɹaɪflɪŋ dɪfəkəlti. ðəɹ wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə taɪ deɪʃɝ. ði æmɪɝlɪn ɔlweɪz hæd sʌmwʌn ɹʌʃɪŋ tə hoʊld əɹ stɝəp ən teɪk əweɪ hɝ hɔɹs, bʌt ʃi stʊd ðəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɡɛldɪŋz ɹeɪnz, ən klʌstɝz ə nɑvəsɪz bʌsəl pæst wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə kwɪk ɡlæns, dɪsmɪsɪŋ əɹ əz wʌn ə ðə vɪzəɾɝz.

She very much wanted to see what she had set in motion. Dismounting in front of the tent, though, she discovered a trifling difficulty. There was nowhere to tie Daishar. The Amyrlin always had someone rushing to hold her stirrup and take away her horse, but she stood there holding the gelding's reins, and clusters of novices bustled past with no more than a quick glance, dismissing her as one of the visitors.

baɪ ðɪs taɪm, ɛvɹi nɑvəs nu ɔl ə ði æksɛptɪɾ ɑn saɪt, bʌt fju hæd sin ði æmɪɝlɪn sit kloʊs ʌp. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv ði eɪdʒləs feɪs tə tɛl əm ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɪð ə ɹufəl læf, ʃi pʊɾ ə ɡlʌv hæn ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ. ðə stoʊl wəd tɛl əm u ʃi wɑz, ən ðən ʃi kəɾ ɔɹɾɝ wʌn ə ðɛm tə hoʊld əɹ hɔɹs fəɹ ə fju mɪnəts. ənlɛs ðeɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə dʒoʊk ɪn bæd teɪst, ət list. səm ə ðə nɑvəsɪz fɹəm ɛmənz fil hæd tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ðə stoʊl fɹəm əɹ nɛk, tə kip əɹ fɹəm ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl. noʊ, ðət wɑz pæst ən dɛlt wɪð.

By this time, every novice knew all of the Accepted on sight, but few had seen the Amyrlin Seat close up. She did not even have the ageless face to tell them she was Aes Sedai. With a rueful laugh, she put a gloved hand into her belt pouch. The stole would tell them who she was, and then she could order one of them to hold her horse for a few minutes. Unless they thought it was a joke in bad taste, at least. Some of the novices from Emond's Field had tried to pull the stole from her neck, to keep her from getting in trouble. No, that was past and dealt with.

əbɹʌpli, ði ɛntʃɹi flæp wɑz pʊʃt oʊpən ən lin ɪmɝdʒd, fæsənɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin kloʊk wɪð ə sɪlvɝ pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə fɪʃ. ðə kloʊk wɑz sɪlk, ən ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn sɪlvɝ ən ɡoʊld, əz wɑz ðə bɑɾəs ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs. hɝ ɹɛd ɡlʌvz wɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə bæks, tu. lin peɪd mɪnəɾ ətɛnʃən tə hɝ kloʊðz sɪns dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. hɝ aɪz waɪɾənd laɪtli ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ɛɡwin, bʌɾ əɹ kɑpɝi feɪs smuðd ɪmiɾiətli. teɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən əɾ ə ɡlæns, ʃi pʊɾ aʊɾ ə hæn tə stɑp ə nɑvəs u əpɪɹd tə bi baɪ hɝsɛlf. nɑvəsɪz wɛn tə klæsəz baɪ fæmli. "wʌts jəɹ neɪm, tʃaɪld?" mʌtʃ hæd tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊt lin, bʌt nɑɾ əɹ bɹɪsknəs. ɪksɛpt wən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪt tə, ɛniweɪ. moʊs mɛn tɝn tə pʌɾi wən linz vɔɪs ɡɹu læŋɔɹəs, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ weɪstəd ðəɾ ɑn wɪmən. "ɑɹ jə ɑn ən ɛɹən fəɹ ə sɪstɝ?" ðə nɑvəs, ə peɪl-aɪd wʊmən kloʊs tə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, wɪð ən ənblɛmɪʃt skɪn ðət hæd nɛvɝ sin ə deɪz wɝk ɪn ðə fild, ɡeɪpt oʊpənli bɪfɔɹ ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ kɝtsi, ə smuðli pɹæktəst spɹɛɾɪŋ ə hɝ waɪt skɝts wɪð mɪɾənd hænz. əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn bʌt wɪləwi ən ɡɹeɪsfəl ən bjuɾəfəl, lin læk ði eɪdʒləs lʊk, tu, jɛt hɝz wɑz wʌn ə ðə tu moʊst wɛl noʊn feɪsəz ɪn ðə kæmp. nɑvəsɪz pɔɪntəɾ əɹ aʊɾ ɪn ɑ, ə sɪstɝ u hæd wʌns bɪn kipɝ, hu hæd bɪn stɪld, ən hil soʊ ʃi kəd tʃænəl əɡɛn, ɪf nɑt soʊ stʃɹɔŋli əz bɪfɔɹ. ən ðən ʃi hæd tʃeɪnʒd ədʒəz! ðə nuəst wɪmən ɪn waɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd lɝn ðət ðət dʒʌs nɛvɝ hæpənd, ðoʊ ði ʌðɝ wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ ə pɑɹɾ ə lɔɹ, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ɪt wɑz hɑɹɾɝ tə meɪk ə nɑvəs ɡoʊ sloʊli wən jə kəd nɑt pɔɪn aʊt ðət ʃi ɹɪskt ɛndɪŋ əɹ kwɛs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl baɪ bɝnɪŋ hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ən luzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɝɛvɝ.

Abruptly, the entry flap was pushed open and Leane emerged, fastening her dark green cloak with a silver pin in the shape of a fish. The cloak was silk, and richly embroidered in silver and gold, as was the bodice of her riding dress. Her red gloves were embroidered on the backs, too. Leane paid minute attention to her clothes since joining the Green Ajah. Her eyes widened lightly at the sight of Egwene, but her coppery face smoothed immediately. Taking in the situation at a glance, she put out a hand to stop a novice who appeared to be by herself. Novices went to classes by family. "What's your name, child?" Much had changed about Leane, but not her briskness. Except when she wanted it to, anyway. Most men turned to putty when Leane's voice grew languorous, but she never wasted that on women. "Are you on an errand for a sister?" The novice, a pale-eyed woman close to her middle years, with an unblemished skin that had never seen a day's work in the field, gaped openly before recovering enough to make her curtsy, a smoothly practiced spreading of her white skirts with mittened hands. As tall as most men but willowy and graceful and beautiful, Leane lacked the ageless look, too, yet hers was one of the two most well known faces in the camp. Novices pointed her out in awe, a sister who had once been Keeper, who had been stilled, and Healed so she could channel again, if not so strongly as before. And then she had changed Ajahs! The newest women in white already had learned that that just never happened, though the other was becoming a part of lore, unfortunately. It was harder to make a novice go slowly when you could not point out that she risked ending her quest for the shawl by burning herself out and losing the One Power forever.

"ləɾəs mɹoʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ðə wʊmən sɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli, ɪn ə lɪltɪŋ mʊɹændiən æksɛnt. ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə seɪ mɔɹ, pɝhæps tə ɡɪv ə taɪɾəl, bʌt wʌn ə ðə fɝs lɛsənz ɑn dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə taʊɝ wɑz ðət jə hæd lɛf bɪhaɪn u jə juz tə bi. ɪt wɑz ə hɑɹd lɛsən, fəɹ sʌm, ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz u pəzɛs taɪɾəlz. "aɪm gɑnə vɪzət maɪ sɪstɝ. aɪ hævən sin əɹ mɔɹ ðən ə mɪnət sɪns bɪfɔɹ wi lɛf mʊɹændi." ɹɛləɾɪvz wɝ ɔlweɪz pʊɾ ɪn dɪfɹənt nɑvəs fæmliz, əz wɝ wɪmən u hæd noʊn itʃ ʌðɝ bɪfɔɹ biɪŋ ɛntɝɾ ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk. ɪɾ ɛnkɝɪdʒ meɪkɪŋ nu fɹɛnz, ən kʌt daʊn ɑn ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl tɛntʃənz wən wʌn wɑz lɝnɪŋ fæstɝ ðən ði ʌðɝ əɹ hæɾ ə haɪɝ pətɛnʃəl.

"Letice Murow, Aes Sedai," the woman said respectfully, in a lilting Murandian accent. She sounded as if she wanted to say more, perhaps to give a title, but one of the first lessons on joining the Tower was that you had left behind who you used to be. It was a hard lesson, for some, especially those who possessed titles. "I'm going to visit my sister. I haven't seen her more than a minute since before we left Murandy." Relatives were always put in different novice families, as were women who had known each other before being entered in the novice book. It encouraged making new friends, and cut down on the inevitable tensions when one was learning faster than the other or had a higher potential.

"ʃiz fɹi ʌv klæsəz, tu, əntɪl ði æftɝnun, ən - " "jɔɹ sɪstɝ wɪl əv tə weɪɾ ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ, tʃaɪld," lin bɹoʊk ɪn. "hoʊl ði æmɪɝlɪnz hɔɹs fəɹ hɝ." ləɾəs ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɛɡwin, hu hæd faɪnəli mænədʒ tə ɪkstʃɹækt əɹ stoʊl. hændɪŋ deɪʃɝz ɹeɪnz tə ðə wʊmən, ʃi loʊɝɾ əɹ kaʊl ən sɛɾəld ðə lɔŋ nɛɹoʊ stʃɹɪp ə klɔθ ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. laɪɾ əz ə fɛðɝ ɪn əɹ paʊtʃ, ðə stoʊl hæd ɹil weɪt hæŋɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. sɪuən kleɪm ðət səmtaɪmz jə kəd fil ɛvɹi wʊmən u hæɾ ɛvɝ wɔɹn ðə stoʊl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ði ɛnz ʌv ɪt, ə kɑnstən ɹimaɪndɝ ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ən duɾi, ən ɛɡwin bɪlivd ɛvɹi wɝd. ðə mʊɹændiən ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ hɑɹɾɝ ðən ʃi hæd fəɹ lin, ən tʊk lɔŋɡɝ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə kɝtsi. noʊ daʊt ʃi hæd hɝd ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz jʌŋ, bʌɾ ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ə θɔt tə haʊ jʌŋ. "θæŋk ju, tʃaɪld," ɛɡwin sɛd smuðli.

"She's free of classes, too, until the afternoon, and - " "Your sister will have to wait a while longer, child," Leane broke in. "Hold the Amyrlin's horse for her." Letice gave a start and stared at Egwene, who had finally managed to extract her stole. Handing Daishar's reins to the woman, she lowered her cowl and settled the long narrow strip of cloth onto her shoulders. Light as a feather in her pouch, the stole had real weight hanging around her neck. Siuan claimed that sometimes you could feel every woman who had ever worn the stole hanging from the ends of it, a constant reminder of responsibility and duty, and Egwene believed every word. The Murandian gaped at her harder than she had for Leane, and took longer to remember to curtsy. No doubt she had heard that the Amyrlin was young, but it seemed unlikely she had given a thought to how young. "Thank you, child," Egwene said smoothly.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə taɪm wən ʃi fɛl stʃɹeɪnʒ kɔlɪŋ ə wʊmən tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən hɝsɛlf tʃaɪld.

There had been a time when she felt strange calling a woman ten years older than herself child.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd, wɪð taɪm. "ɪt woʊn bi fəɹ lɔŋ. lin, wəd jə æsk sʌmwʌn tə sɛn ə ɡɹum fəɹ deɪʃɝ? naʊ ðəɾ aɪm aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl, aɪɾ əz sun steɪ aʊt, ən ləɾəs ʃəd bi əlaʊd tə si hɝ sɪstɝ."

Everything changed, with time. "It won't be for long. Leane, would you ask someone to send a groom for Daishar? Now that I'm out of the saddle, I'd as soon stay out, and Letice should be allowed to see her sister."

"aɪ wɪl si tə ɪt maɪsɛlf, mʌðɝ."

"I will see to it myself, Mother."

lin ɔfɝɾ ə fluəd kɝtsi ən muvd əweɪ wɪð nɛvɝ ə hɪn ðət ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ bɪtwin əm ðən ðɪs tʃæns ɪnkaʊntɝ. ɛɡwin tʃɹʌstɪɾ əɹ fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪɾ æneɪjə əɹ ivən ʃɛɹiəm. ʃi sɝɾənli kɛp noʊ sikɹəts fɹəm lin, ɛni mɔɹ ðən fɹəm sɪuən. bʌt ðɛɹ fɹɛndʃɪp wɑz jɛɾ ənʌðɝ sikɹət ðət hæd tə bi kɛpt. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, lin hæɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz æktʃəli  ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪf nɑɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, ən ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts keɪm tə ɛɡwin ən ɛɡwin əloʊn. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, lin wɑz mʌtʃ pɛɾəd fəɹ əkɑmədeɪɾɪŋ soʊ wɛl tə hɝ ɹədust stæɾəs, ən ɛvɹi sɪstɝ wɛlkəm hɝ, ɪf oʊnli kəz ʃi wɑz lɪvɪŋ pɹuf ðət stɪlɪŋ, ðə dipəs dʒɹɛɾ ʌv ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, kəd bi ɹɪvɝst. ðeɪ wɛlkəmd əɹ wɪð oʊpən ɑɹmz, ən kəz ʃi wɑz lɛs, naʊ, stændɪŋ bɪloʊ ət lis hæf ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə kæmp, ðeɪ ɔfən spoʊk ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ əbaʊt mæɾɝz ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ wɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn tə noʊ ʌv. soʊ ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns æftɝ əɹ əz ʃi lɛft. ɪnstɛd, ʃi, ɔfɝd ləɾəs ə smaɪl - ðə wʊmən ɹɛɾənd ən bɑbd ənʌðɝ kɝtsi - ðən ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt, stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɔf əɹ ɡlʌvz ən tʌkɪŋ əm bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt.

Leane offered a fluid curtsy and moved away with never a hint that there was more between them than this chance encounter. Egwene trusted her far more than she did Anaiya or even Sheriam. She certainly kept no secrets from Leane, any more than from Siuan. But their friendship was yet another secret that had to be kept. For one thing, Leane had eyes-and-ears actually inside Tar Valon if not in the Tower itself, and their reports came to Egwene and Egwene alone. For another, Leane was much petted for accommodating so well to her reduced status, and every sister welcomed her, if only because she was living proof that stilling, the deepest dread of any Aes Sedai, could be reversed. They welcomed her with open arms, and because she was less, now, standing below at least half the sisters in the camp, they often spoke in front of her about matters they would never want the Amyrlin to know of. So Egwene did not so much as glance after her as she left. Instead, she, offered Letice a smile - the woman reddened and bobbed another curtsy - then entered the tent, stripping off her gloves and tucking them behind her belt.

ɪnsaɪd, eɪt mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps stʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz bɪtwin loʊ wʊɾən tʃɛsts. wʌn wɪð ə bɪɾ ʌv wɔɹn ɡɪldɪŋ ən ðə ɹɛst ə peɪntəɾ aɪɝn, noʊ tu ʌv ðə læmps hæd ðə seɪm nʌmbɝ ʌv ɑɹmz, bʌt ðeɪ pɹəvaɪɾəd ɡʊɾ ɪluməneɪʃən, ɪf nɑt soʊ bɹaɪɾ əz aʊtsaɪd. əsɔɹɾɪd teɪbəlz ðət sim tə hæv kʌm fɹəm sɛvən dɪfɹən fɑɹm kɪtʃənz meɪɾ ə ɹoʊ daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kænvəs ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ, ðə bɛntʃɪz ə ðə θɹi fɑɹðəst ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ə hæf ə dʌzən nɑvəsɪz wɪð ðɛɹ kloʊks foʊldəd bɪsaɪd ðɛm, itʃ wʊmən sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ. tiɑnə, ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, hʌvɝɾ æŋkʃəsli oʊvɝ ðɛm, wɔkɪŋ bɪtwin ðə teɪbəlz, ən sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, soʊ dɪd ʃɛɝinə mɛlɔɪ, wʌn ə ðə nɑvəsɪz əkwaɪɝɾ ɪn mʊɹændi.

Inside, eight mirrored stand-lamps stood along the walls between low wooden chests. One with a bit of worn gilding and the rest of painted iron, no two of the lamps had the same number of arms, but they provided good illumination, if not so bright as outside. Assorted tables that seemed to have come from seven different farm kitchens made a row down the center of the canvas ground-cloth, the benches of the three farthest occupied by a half a dozen novices with their cloaks folded beside them, each woman surrounded by the glow of the Power. Tiana, the Mistress of Novices, hovered anxiously over them, walking between the tables, and surprisingly, so did Sharina Melloy, one of the novices acquired in Murandy.

wɛl, ʃɛɝinə wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli hʌvɝɪŋ, dʒʌst wɑtʃɪŋ kɑmli, ən pɝhæps ɪt ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ə sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn əɹ ðɛɹ. ə dɪɡnəfaɪd, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd ɡɹændmʌðɝ wɪð ə taɪt bʌn ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, ʃɛɝinə hæd ɹʌn ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ fæmli wɪð ə vɛɹi fɝm hænd, ən ʃi sim tə hæv ədɑptəɾ ɔl ə ði ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz əz ɡɹændɔɾɝz əɹ ɡɹændnisəz. ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u hæɾ ɔɹɡənaɪzd əm ɪndə ðoʊz taɪni fæmliz, kəmplitli ɑn əɹ oʊn ən əpɛɹənli aʊɾ ə sɪmpəl dɪsɡʌst ət siɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn flaʊndɝ ɝaʊnd. moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn mɔɹ ðən ə tʌtʃ taɪt-maʊðd ɪf ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðæt, ðoʊ ðeɪ hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðə fɔɹm kwɪkli ɪnʌf wʌns ðeɪ ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ ɪt meɪd kipɪŋ tʃɹæk ən ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ klæsəz. tiɑnə wɑz ɪnspɛktɪŋ ðə nɑvəsɪz' wɝk soʊ kloʊsli ðəɾ ɪt simd ɑbviəs ʃi wɑz ətɛmptɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ʃɛɝinəz pɹɛzəns. ʃɔɹɾ ən slaɪt, wɪð lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn aɪz ən ə dɪmpəl ɪn əɹ tʃik, tiɑnə sʌmhaʊ lʊk jʌŋ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ eɪdʒləs feɪs, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli əlɔŋsaɪd ðə tɔlɝ nɑvəsəz kɹis tʃiks ən bɹɔd hɪps.

Well, Sharina was not exactly hovering, just watching calmly, and perhaps it should not have been a surprise to find her there. A dignified, gray-haired grandmother with a tight bun on the back of her head, Sharina had run a very large family with a very firm hand, and she seemed to have adopted all of the other novices as granddaughters or grandnieces. She was the one who had organized them into those tiny families, completely on her own and apparently out of simple disgust at seeing everyone flounder around. Most Aes Sedai went more than a touch tight-mouthed if reminded of that, though they had accepted the form quickly enough once they realized how much easier it made keeping track and organizing classes. Tiana was inspecting the novices' work so closely that it seemed obvious she was attempting to ignore Sharina's presence. Short and slight, with large brown eyes and a dimple in her cheek, Tiana somehow looked young despite her ageless face, particularly alongside the taller novice's creased cheeks and broad hips.

ðə pɛɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃænəlɪŋ ət ðə teɪbəl nɪɹəs ði ɛntʃɹəns, kɛɹən ən æʃmɑneɪl, hæɾ ən ɑɾiəns ə tu əz wɛl, dʒɑnjə fɹɛnd, ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn, ən sæliɾə tɔɹeɪnz, ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə jɛloʊ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə nɑvəsɪz wɝ ɔl pɝfɔɹmɪŋ ðə seɪm tæsk. ɪn fɹʌn ʌv itʃ wʊmən, ə kloʊs nɛt woʊvən ə ɝθ, faɪɝ ən ɛɹ sɝaʊndəɾ ə smɔl boʊl əɹ kʌp əɹ ðə laɪk, ɔl meɪd baɪ ðə kæmps blæksmɪθs, hu wɝ vɛɹi pʌzəld ət waɪ ðə sɪstɝz wɑntəd sətʃ θɪŋz meɪɾ ʌv aɪɝn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən hævɪŋ əm meɪɾ əz faɪnli əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ sɪlvɝ. ə sɛkənd wiv, ɝθ ən faɪɝ woʊvən dʒʌst soʊ, pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd itʃ nɛt tə tʌtʃ ði ɑbʒɛkt, wɪtʃ wɑz sloʊli tɝnɪŋ waɪt. vɛɹi, vɛɹi sloʊli, ɪn ɛvɹi keɪs. əbɪləɾi wɪð ðə wiv ɪmpɹuvd wɪð pɹæktəs, bʌɾ ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz, stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ɝθ wɑz ðə ki, ən bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf, oʊnli naɪn sɪstɝz ɪn ðə kæmp - əlɔŋ wɪð tu ʌv ði æksɛptɪɾ ən nɪɹli tu dʌzən nɑvəsɪz - hæd səfɪʃən ə ðət tə meɪk ðə wivz wɝk əɾ ɔl. fju əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz wɑntəd tə ɡɪv ɛni taɪm tə ɪt, ðoʊ. æʃmɑneɪl, lin ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ sim tɔlɝ ðən ʃi ɹɪli wɑz, fɪŋɡɝz tæpɪŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə sɪmpəl mɛɾəl kʌp ɪn fɹʌn hɝ, wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli əz ði ɛdʒ ʌv waɪtnəs kɹɛpt ʌpwɝd pæs hæfweɪ. kɛɹənz blu aɪz wɝ koʊld ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪt simd əɹ stɛɹ əloʊn maɪt ʃæɾɝ ðə tɔl ɡɑblət ʃi wɑz wɝkɪŋ ɑn. ðət hæɾ oʊnli ðə smɔləst ɹɪm ʌv waɪɾ ət ðə bɑɾəm. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn kɛɹən ɛɡwin hæd sin ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn.

The pair of Aes Sedai channeling at the table nearest the entrance, Kairen and Ashmanaille, had an audience of two as well, Janya Frende, a Sitter for the Brown, and Salita Toranes, a Sitter for the Yellow. The Aes Sedai and the novices were all performing the same task. In front of each woman, a close net woven of Earth, Fire and Air surrounded a small bowl or cup or the like, all made by the camp's blacksmiths, who were very puzzled at why the sisters wanted such things made of iron, not to mention having them made as finely as if they were silver. A second weave, Earth and Fire woven just so, penetrated each net to touch the object, which was slowly turning white. Very, very slowly, in every case. Ability with the weave improved with practice, but of the Five Powers, strength in Earth was the key, and beside Egwene herself, only nine sisters in the camp - along with two of the Accepted and nearly two dozen novices - had sufficient of that to make the weaves work at all. Few among the sisters wanted to give any time to it, though. Ashmanaille, lean enough to make her seem taller than she really was, fingers tapping the tabletop on either side of the simple metal cup in front her, was frowning impatiently as the edge of whiteness crept upward past halfway. Kairen's blue eyes were cold enough that it seemed her stare alone might shatter the tall goblet she was working on. That had only the smallest rim of white at the bottom. It must have been Kairen Egwene had seen going in.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ənɪnθuziæstɪk, ðoʊ. dʒɑnjə, slɪm ɪn əɹ peɪl bɹɑnz sɪlks ən wɛɹɪŋ əɹ bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹmz, stʌɾid wʌt kɛɹən ən æʃmɑneɪl wɝ duɪŋ wɪð ði iɡɝnəs ʌv wʌn u wɪʃt ʃi kəd bi duɪŋ ðə seɪm. dʒɑnjə wɑntəd tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, tə noʊ haʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz dʌn ən waɪ ɪt hæpən ðət weɪ. ʃi hæd bɪn ɪkstʃɹimli dɪsəpɔɪntɪd wən ʃi kəd nɑt lɝn tə meɪk tɛɹæŋɡɹil - oʊnli θɹi sɪstɝz əsaɪd fɹəm ɪleɪn hæd mænədʒ ðæt, soʊ fɑɹ, wɪð vɛɹi spɑɾi səksɛs - ən ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə kənsɝɾəd ɛfɝt tə lɝn ðɪs skɪl ivən æftɝ ðə tɛstɪŋ ʃoʊd ʃi fɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə ɹikwaɪɝd stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn juzɪŋ ɝθ.

Not everyone was unenthusiastic, though. Janya, slim in her pale bronze silks and wearing her brown-fringed shawl draped over her arms, studied what Kairen and Ashmanaille were doing with the eagerness of one who wished she could be doing the same. Janya wanted to know everything, to know how everything was done and why it happened that way. She had been extremely disappointed when she could not learn to make ter'angreal - only three sisters aside from Elayne had managed that, so far, with very spotty success - and she had made a concerted effort to learn this skill even after the testing showed she fell short of the required strength in using Earth.

sæliɾə wɑz ðə fɝs tə noʊɾəs ɛɡwin. ɹaʊnd-feɪst ən ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz tʃɑɹkoʊl, ʃi aɪɾ ɛɡwin lɛvəli, ən ðə jɛloʊ fɹɪnʒ ə hɝ ʃɔl sweɪd slaɪtli əz ʃi meɪɾ ə vɛɹi pɹɪsaɪs kɝtsi, ɪɡzæk tə ði ɪntʃ. ɹeɪzd ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, sæliɾə wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ə dɪstɝbɪŋ pæɾɝn: tu mɛni sɪɾɝz u wɝ tu jʌŋ fəɹ ðə pəzɪʃən. sæliɾə hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ θɝɾi-faɪv jɪɹz, ən ɹɛɹli wɑz ə wʊmən ɡɪvən ə tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ wɛɹɪŋ ðə ʃɔl fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ. sɪuən sɔ ə pæɾɝn, ɛniweɪ, ən θɔɾ ɪt dɪstɝbɪŋ, ðoʊ ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ waɪ. pæɾɝnz ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɔlweɪz dɪstɝb sɪuən.

Salita was the first to notice Egwene. Round-faced and almost as dark as charcoal, she eyed Egwene levelly, and the Yellow fringe of her shawl swayed slightly as she made a very precise curtsy, exact to the inch. Raised in Salidar, Salita was part of a disturbing pattern: too many Sitters who were too young for the position. Salita had only been Aes Sedai for thirty-five years, and rarely was a woman given a chair before wearing the shawl for a hundred or more. Siuan saw a pattern, anyway, and thought it disturbing, though she could not say why. Patterns she could not understand always disturbed Siuan.

stɪl, sæliɾə hæd stʊd fəɹ wɔɹ əɡɛnst ɪleɪɾə, ən fɹikwənli səpɔɹɾəd ɛɡwin ɪn ðə hɔl. bʌt nɑɾ ɔlweɪz, ən nɑɾ ɪn ðɪs. "mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd kuli. dʒɑnjəz hɛd dʒɝkt ʌp, ən ʃi bɹoʊk ɪndə ə bimɪŋ smaɪl. ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæd stʊd fəɹ wɔɹ, ði oʊnli wʊmən u hæd bɪn ə sɪɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə taʊɝ dɪvaɪɾəd tə də soʊ ɛksɛptɪŋ ləleɪn ən laɪɹɛl, tu ʌv ðə bluz, ən ɪf əɹ səpɔɹt fəɹ ɛɡwin wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ənweɪvɝɪŋ, ɪt wɑz soʊ hɪɹ. əz juʒəwəl, wɝdz spɪld aʊɾ ə hɝ. "aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðɪs, mʌðɝ. ɪts sɪmpli əmeɪzɪŋ. aɪ noʊ wi ʃʊdn bi sɝpɹaɪzd ɛni lɔŋɡɝ wən jə kʌm ʌp wɪð sʌmθɪŋ noʊ wʌn ɛls əz θɔɾ ʌv - səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk wiv ɡɑɾən tu sɛɾ ɪn əɹ weɪz, tu ʃʊɹ wʌt kən ən kænɑt bi dʌn - bʌt tə pʌzəl aʊt haʊ tə meɪk kwəndɪlɝ . . . !" ʃi pɔz fəɹ bɹɛθ, ən sæliɾə muvd ɪndə ðə ɡæp smuðli. ən koʊldli. "aɪ stɪl seɪ ɪts ɹɔŋ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ ədmɪt ðə dɪskʌvɝi wɑz ə bɹɪljən pis ʌv wɝk ɑn jəɹ pɑɹt, mʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃəd nɑt bi meɪkɪŋ θɪŋz fəɹ . . . seɪl." sæliɾə ɪnvɛstəd ðət wɝd wɪð ɔl ðə skɔɹn ʌv ə wʊmən u æksɛptɪd ði ɪnkʌm fɹəm əɹ ɪsteɪɾ ɪn tiɹ wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ θɪŋkɪŋ haʊ ɪt hæd bɪn kʌm baɪ. ði æɾətud wɑz nɑɾ ənkɑmən, ðoʊ moʊst sɪstɝz lɪvd ɑn ðə taʊɝz dʒɛnɝəs jɪɹli əlaʊəns. əɹ hæd, bɪfɔɹ ðə taʊɝ splɪɾ əpɑɹt. "ɑn tɑp ʌv wɪtʃ," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "nɪɹli hæf ðə sɪstɝz fɔɹst ɪndə ðɪs ɑɹ jɛloʊ. aɪ ɹəsiv kəmpleɪns ɛvɹi deɪ.

Still, Salita had stood for war against Elaida, and frequently supported Egwene in the Hall. But not always, and not in this. "Mother," she said coolly. Janya's head jerked up, and she broke into a beaming smile. She also had stood for war, the only woman who had been a Sitter before the Tower divided to do so excepting Lelaine and Lyrelle, two of the Blues, and if her support for Egwene was not always unwavering, it was so here. As usual, words spilled out of her. "I will never get over this, Mother. It's simply amazing. I know we shouldn't be surprised any longer when you come up with something no one else has thought of - sometimes I think we've gotten too set in our ways, too sure what can and cannot be done - but to puzzle out how to make cuendillar . . . !" She paused for breath, and Salita moved into the gap smoothly. And coldly. "I still say it is wrong," she said firmly. "I admit the discovery was a brilliant piece of work on your part, Mother, but Aes Sedai should not be making things for . . . sale." Salita invested that word with all the scorn of a woman who accepted the income from her estate in Tear without ever thinking how it had been come by. The attitude was not uncommon, though most sisters lived on the Tower's generous yearly allowance. Or had, before the Tower split apart. "On top of which," she went on, "nearly half the sisters forced into this are Yellow. I receive complaints every day.

wi, ət list, hæv mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt jusəz fəɹ əɹ taɪm ðən meɪkɪŋ . . . tʃɹɪŋkəts." ðəɾ ɝn əɹ ə hɑɹd ɡlɛɹ fɹəm æʃmɑneɪl, ə ɡɹeɪ, ən ə fɹɪdʒəd stɛɹ fɹəm kɛɹən, hu wɑz blu, bʌt sæliɾə ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm.

We, at least, have more important uses for our time than making . . . trinkets." That earned her a hard glare from Ashmanaille, a Gray, and a frigid stare from Kairen, who was Blue, but Salita ignored them.

ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz jɛloʊz u sim tə θɪŋk ði ʌðɝ ədʒəz wɝ oʊnli ædʒʌŋks tə hɝ oʊn, wɪtʃ ə kɔɹs hæd ði oʊnli tʃɹuli jusfəl pɝpəs əmʌŋ ðɛm.

She was one of those Yellows who seemed to think the other Ajahs were only adjuncts to her own, which of course had the only truly useful purpose among them.

"ænd nɑvəsɪz ʃəd nɑt bi duɪŋ wivz ə ðɪs kəmplɛksəɾi əɾ ɔl," tiɑnə æɾəd, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðɛm.

"And novices should not be doing weaves of this complexity at all," Tiana added, joining them.

ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz wɑz nɛvɝ ʃaɪ əbaʊt spikɪŋ ʌp tə sɪɾɝz, əɹ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə dɪsɡɹʌntəld ɪkspɹɛʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt dipən əɹ dɪmpəl ən meɪɾ əɹ lʊk sʌlki. "ɪɾ ɪz ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl dɪskʌvɝi, ən aɪ fəɹ wʌn əv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə tʃɹeɪd, bʌt səm ə ðiz ɡɝlz kən bɛɹli mænədʒ tə meɪk ə bɔl ə faɪɝ tʃeɪnʒ kʌlɝ wɪð ɛni ʃʊɹəɾi. lɛɾɪŋ əm hændəl wivz laɪk ðɪs wɪl oʊnli meɪk ɪt mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə stɑp əm fɹəm lipɪŋ tə θɪŋz ðeɪ kæn hændəl, ən ðə laɪt noʊz, ðæts dɪfəkəlt ɪnʌf ɔlɹɛɾi. ðeɪ meɪ ivən də ðɛmsɛlvz ən ɪnʒɝi."

The Mistress of Novices was never shy about speaking up to Sitters, or to the Amyrlin, and she wore a disgruntled expression. She did not appear to realize that it deepened her dimple and made her look sulky. "It is a remarkable discovery, and I for one have no objections to trade, but some of these girls can barely manage to make a ball of fire change color with any surety. Letting them handle weaves like this will only make it more difficult to stop them from leaping to things they can't handle, and the Light knows, that's difficult enough already. They may even do themselves an injury."

"nɑnsɛns, nɑnsɛns," dʒɑnjə ɪkskleɪmd, weɪvɪŋ ə slɛndɝ hæn əz ɪf tə bɹʌʃ əweɪ ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə. "ɛvɹi ɡɝl huz bɪn tʃoʊzən kən ɔlɹɛɾi meɪk θɹi bɔlz ə faɪɝ ət wʌns, ən ðɪs ɹikwaɪɝz vɛɹi lɪɾəl mɔɹ ə ðə paʊɝ. ðɛɹz noʊ deɪnʒɝ əɾ ɔl, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðəɹ ʌndɝ ə sɪstɝz supɝvɪʒən, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ɑɹ. aɪv sin ðə ɹɑstɝ. bɪsaɪdz, wʌt wi meɪk ɪn ə deɪ wɪl bɹɪŋ ɪnʌf tə peɪ ði ɑɹmi fəɹ ə wik əɹ mɔɹ, bʌt ðə sɪstɝz əloʊn kæn pɹədus nɪɹ ðət mʌtʃ." skwɪntɪŋ slaɪtli, ʃi sʌɾənli əpɪɹd tə bi lʊkɪŋ θɹu tiɑnə. ðə kæskeɪd fɹəm əɹ tʌŋ nɛvɝ sloʊd, jɛt ʃi sim tə bi tɔkɪŋ ət lis hæf tə hɝsɛlf. "wi wɪl əv tə teɪk ɡɹeɪt kɛɹ ɪn ðə sɛlɪŋ. ðə si foʊk əv ə vɔɹeɪʃəs æpətaɪt fəɹ kwəndɪlɝ, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ plɛnti ʌv ðɛɹ ʃɪps stɪl əɾ ɪljən ən tiɹ baɪ ɔl əkaʊns - ðə noʊbəlz ðəɹ ɑɹ ɡɹiɾi fəɹ ɪt, tu - bʌɾ ivən ɹævənəs æpətaɪts əv lɪməts. aɪ stɪl kænɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ɪɾəl bi bɛs tə əpɪɹ wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ ət wʌns, əɹ lɛɾ ɪt tʃɹɪkəl aʊt. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ivən ðə pɹaɪs ə kwəndɪlɝ wɪl bɪɡɪn tə dʒɹɑp." əbɹʌpli ʃi blɪŋkt ən pɪɹd fɝst ət tiɑnə ðən ət sæliɾə, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə wʌn saɪd. "ju də si maɪ pɔɪnt, doʊn ju?" sæliɾə ɡlaʊɝɾ ən hɪtʃt əɹ ʃɔl ʌp ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

"Nonsense, nonsense," Janya exclaimed, waving a slender hand as if to brush away the very idea. "Every girl who's been chosen can already make three balls of fire at once, and this requires very little more of the Power. There's no danger at all, so long as they're under a sister's supervision, and they always are. I've seen the roster. Besides, what we make in a day will bring enough to pay the army for a week or more, but the sisters alone can't produce near that much." Squinting slightly, she suddenly appeared to be looking through Tiana. The cascade from her tongue never slowed, yet she seemed to be talking at least half to herself. "We will have to take great care in the selling. The Sea Folk have a voracious appetite for cuendillar, and there are plenty of their ships still at Illian and Tear by all accounts - the nobles there are greedy for it, too - but even ravenous appetites have limits. I still cannot decide whether it will be best to appear with everything at once, or let it trickle out. Sooner or later, even the price of cuendillar will begin to drop." Abruptly she blinked and peered first at Tiana then at Salita, tilting her head to one side. "You do see my point, don't you?" Salita glowered and hitched her shawl up on her shoulders.

tiɑnə θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. ɛɡwin hɛld əɹ pis. fəɹ wʌns, ʃi fɛl noʊ ʃeɪm ət biɪŋ pɹeɪz fəɹ wʌn ə hɝ səpoʊz dɪskʌvɝiz. ənlaɪk nɪɹli ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪksɛp tʃɹævlɪŋ, ðɪs wʌn æktʃəli  wɑz hɝz, ðoʊ mɑɡiɾin hæd pɔɪntəd ðə weɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɪskeɪpt. ðə wʊmən dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə æktʃəli  meɪk ɛniθɪŋ - ət list, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪvild ɛni sətʃ nɑlədʒ haʊɛvɝ hɑɹɾ ɛɡwin hæd pɹɛs hɝ, ən ʃi hæd pɹɛs vɛɹi hɑɹd - bʌt mɑɡiɾin hæɾ ə waɪd stʃɹik ʌv ɡɹid, ən ivən ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, kwəndɪlɝ hæd bɪn ə pɹaɪz lʌɡʒɝi. ʃi hæd noʊn ɪnʌf ə haʊ ɪt wɑz meɪd fəɹ ɛɡwin tə pʌzəl aʊt ðə ɹɛst. ɪn ɛni keɪs, noʊ mæɾɝ u əbdʒɛktəɾ əɹ haʊ stʃɹɛnjuəsli, ðə nid fəɹ mʌni mɛn ðə pɹədʌkʃən ə kwəndɪlɝ wəd kəntɪnju. ðoʊ əz fɑɹ əz ʃi wɑz kənsɝnd, ðə lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌv ɪt wɑz soʊld, ðə bɛɾɝ.

Tiana threw up her hands in exasperation. Egwene held her peace. For once, she felt no shame at being praised for one of her supposed discoveries. Unlike nearly everything else except Traveling, this one actually was hers, though Moghedien had pointed the way before she escaped. The woman did not know how to actually make anything - at least, she had not revealed any such knowledge however hard Egwene had pressed her, and she had pressed very hard - but Moghedien had a wide streak of greed, and even in the Age of Legends, cuendillar had been a prized luxury. She had known enough of how it was made for Egwene to puzzle out the rest. In any case, no matter who objected or how strenuously, the need for money meant the production of cuendillar would continue. Though as far as she was concerned, the longer before any of it was sold, the better.

ʃɛɝinə slæpɪŋ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ laʊdli ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə tɛn dʒɝkt ɛvɹiwʌnz hɛd ðət weɪ. kɛɹən ən æʃmɑneɪl tɝnd, tu, ðə blu ivən lɛɾɪŋ əɹ wivz ɡoʊ soʊ ðə ɡɑblət baʊnst ɑn ðə teɪbəltɑp wɪð ə mətælɪk klæɾɝ. ɪt wɑz ə saɪn ə bɔɹɾəm. ðə pɹɑsɛs kəd bi stɑɹɾəd oʊvɝ, ðoʊ faɪndɪŋ ðə pɹɪsaɪs pɔɪnt wɑz vɛɹi hɑɹd, ən səm sɪstɝz tʊk ɛvɹi ɑpɝtunəɾi tə də ɛniθɪŋ ɛls dʊɹɪŋ ði aʊɝ ðeɪ hæd tə spɛn ɪn ðə tɛn itʃ deɪ. ən aʊɝ əɹ əntɪl ðeɪ kəmpliɾəd wʌn aɪɾəm stɑɹt tə fɪnɪʃ, wɪtʃɛvɝ keɪm fɝst. ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə pʊʃ əm tə tʃɹaɪ hɑɹɾɝ əɾ ɪnkɹisɪŋ ðɛɹ skɪl, bʌt fju hæd pɹəɡɹɛs vɛɹi fɑɹ. "boʊɾuwɪn, nɪkoʊlə, ɔf tə jəɹ nɛks klæs," ʃɛɝinə ənaʊnst. ʃi dɪd nɑt spik laʊdli, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs hæɾ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ðət cʊɾə kʌt θɹu ə bæbəl ə vɔɪsəz mʌtʃ lɛs ðə kwaɪəɾ ə ðə tɛnt. "ju hæv dʒʌs taɪm tə wɑʃ jəɹ hænz ən feɪsəz. kwɪkli, naʊ.

Sharina slapping her hands together loudly in the back of the tent jerked everyone's head that way. Kairen and Ashmanaille turned, too, the Blue even letting her weaves go so the goblet bounced on the tabletop with a metallic clatter. It was a sign of boredom. The process could be started over, though finding the precise point was very hard, and some sisters took every opportunity to do anything else during the hour they had to spend in the tent each day. An hour or until they completed one item start to finish, whichever came first. That was supposed to push them to try harder at increasing their skill, but few had progressed very far. "Bodewhin, Nicola, off to your next class," Sharina announced. She did not speak loudly, but her voice had a strength that could have cut through a babble of voices much less the quiet of the tent. "You have just time to wash your hands and faces. Quickly, now.

jə doʊnt wɑn ɛni bæd ɹɪpɔɹts."

You don't want any bad reports."

boʊd - boʊɾuwɪn - muvd wɪð ɪfɪʃən əlækɹəɾi, ɹilisɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ ən pleɪsɪŋ əɹ hæf-meɪd kwəndɪlɝ bɹeɪsləɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðə tʃɛsts əlɔŋ ðə wɔl fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls tə fɪnɪʃ, ðən ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ kloʊk. plʌmp-tʃikt ən pɹɪɾi, ʃi wɔɹ əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ dɑɹk bɹeɪd, ðoʊ ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən pɝmɪʃən fɹəm ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl. bʌt ðɛn, ðət wɝld wɑz bɪhaɪn hɝ, naʊ. tʌɡɪŋ ɑn əɹ mɪɾənz əz ʃi hɝid fɹəm ðə tɛnt, boʊd kɛpt əɹ aɪz daʊn ən nɛvɝ ɡlænst ɪn ɛɡwinz dɝɛkʃən. pleɪnli, ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ə nɑvəs kəd nɑt dʒɹɑp baɪ tə tʃæt wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɛnɛvɝ ʃi wɑntəd, ivən ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp təɡɛðɝ.

Bode - Bodewhin - moved with efficient alacrity, releasing saidar and placing her half-made cuendillar bracelet in one of the chests along the wall for someone else to finish, then gathering her cloak. Plump-cheeked and pretty, she wore her hair in a long dark braid, though Egwene was not sure she had gotten permission from the Women's Circle. But then, that world was behind her, now. Tugging on her mittens as she hurried from the tent, Bode kept her eyes down and never glanced in Egwene's direction. Plainly, she still did not understand why a novice could not drop by to chat with the Amyrlin Seat whenever she wanted, even if they had grown up together.

ɛɡwin wʊɾə lʌv tə tɔk wɪð boʊɾ ən səm ə ði ʌðɝz, bʌɾ ən æmɪɝlɪn hæd lɛsənz tə lɝn, tu. ən æmɪɝlɪn hæd mɛni duɾiz, fju fɹɛnz, ən noʊ feɪvɹɪts. bɪsaɪdz, ivən ði əpɪɹəns ə feɪvɝɪtɪzəm wəd mɑɹk ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɡɝlz aʊɾ ən meɪk ðɛɹ laɪvz wɪð ði ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz ə mɪzɝi.

Egwene would have loved to talk with Bode and some of the others, but an Amyrlin had lessons to learn, too. An Amyrlin had many duties, few friends, and no favorites. Besides, even the appearance of favoritism would mark the Two Rivers girls out and make their lives with the other novices a misery.

ən ɪt wʊdn də mi mʌtʃ ɡʊd wɪð ðə hɔl, iðɝ, ʃi θɔt ɹaɪli. ʃi dɪd wɪʃ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɡɝlz ʌndɝstʊd, ðoʊ.

And it wouldn't do me much good with the Hall, either, she thought wryly. She did wish the Two Rivers girls understood, though.

ði ʌðɝ nɑvəs ʃɛɝinə hæd neɪm dɪd nɑt liv əɹ bɛntʃ əɹ stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ. nɪkoʊləz blæk aɪz flæʃt ət ʃɛɝinə. "aɪ kəd bi ðə bɛst ət ðɪs ɪf aɪ wɑz ɛvɝ əlaʊd tə ɹɪli pɹæktəs," ʃi ɹʌmbəl sʌlənli. "aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ; aɪ noʊ aɪ æm. aɪ kən fɔɹtɛl, jə noʊ." əz ɪf ðə wʌn hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ði ʌðɝ. "tiɑnə sədaɪ, tɛl əɹ aɪ kən steɪ lɔŋɡɝ. aɪ kən fɪnɪʃ ðɪs boʊl bɪfɔɹ maɪ nɛks klæs, ən aɪm ʃʊɹ ɑdini sədaɪ woʊn maɪn ɪf aɪm dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl leɪt." ɪf əɹ klæs wɑz ɛni taɪm sun, ʃi wəd bi mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl leɪɾ ɪf ʃi tɑɹid tə kəmplit ðə boʊl; hɝ aʊɝz ɛfɝt hæd tɝn oʊnli hæf ʌv ɪt waɪt.

The other novice Sharina had named did not leave her bench or stop channeling. Nicola's black eyes flashed at Sharina. "I could be the best at this if I was ever allowed to really practice," she rumbled sullenly. "I'm getting better; I know I am. I can Foretell, you know." As if the one had anything to do with the other. "Tiana Sedai, tell her I can stay longer. I can finish this bowl before my next class, and I'm sure Adine Sedai won't mind if I'm just a little late." If her class was any time soon, she would be more than a little late if she tarried to complete the bowl; her hour's effort had turned only half of it white.

tiɑnə oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ʌɾɝ ə wɝd, ʃɛɝinə ɹeɪzd wʌn fɪŋɡɝ, ðən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ə sɛkənd. ɪt mʌst əv hæd səm pɝtɪkjəlɝ səɡnɪfɪkəns, kəz nɪkoʊlə wɛn peɪl ən lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv əɹ wivz ɑn ði ɪnstənt, lipɪŋ ʌp soʊ kwɪkli ðət ʃi dʒɑɡəl ðə bɛntʃ, ɝnɪŋ kwɪk fɹaʊnz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ tu nɑvəsɪz u ʃɛɹɾ ɪt. ðeɪ bɛn kwɪkli bæk tə ðɛɹ wɝk, ðoʊ, ən nɪkoʊlə ɔlmoʊst ɹæn tə θɹʌs ðə hæf-dʌn boʊl ɪndə ə tʃɛs bɪfɔɹ snætʃɪŋ ʌp əɹ kloʊk. tə ɛɡwinz sɝpɹaɪz, ə wʊmən ʃi hæd nɑt sin, dʒɹɛst ɪn ə ʃɔɹt bɹaʊn koʊɾ ən waɪd tʃɹaʊzɝz, dʒʌmpt ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ bɪɑn ðə teɪbəlz. skaʊlɪŋ blu-aɪd dæɡɝz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt, ɑɹinə ɹæn aʊɾ ə ðə tɛn æftɝ nɪkoʊlə, ðə tu wɪmən mɪɹɝ ɪmədʒəz ə dɪsɡɹʌntəlmən ən dɪskəntɛnt.

Tiana opened her mouth, but before she could utter a word, Sharina raised one finger, then a moment later, a second. It must have had some particular significance, because Nicola went pale and let go of her weaves on the instant, leaping up so quickly that she joggled the bench, earning quick frowns from the other two novices who shared it. They bent quickly back to their work, though, and Nicola almost ran to thrust the half-done bowl into a chest before snatching up her cloak. To Egwene's surprise, a woman she had not seen, dressed in a short brown coat and wide trousers, jumped up from where she had been sitting on the ground-cloth beyond the tables. Scowling blue-eyed daggers at everyone in sight, Areina ran out of the tent after Nicola, the two women mirror images of disgruntlement and discontent.

siɪŋ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm təɡɛðɝ meɪɾ ɛɡwin ənizi. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ fɹɛnz wɝ əlaʊɾ ɪn hɪɹ tə wɑtʃ," ʃi sɛd. "ɪz nɪkoʊlə stɪl kɑzɪŋ pɹɑbləmz?" nɪkoʊlə ən ɑɹinə hæɾ ətɛmptəd tə blækmeɪl hɝ, ən maɪɹɛl ən naɪsaʊ, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt ʃi mɛnt. ðət wɑz stɪl ənʌðɝ sikɹət. "bɛɾɝ ðə ɡɝlz fɹɛnli wɪð ɑɹinə ðən wɪð wʌn ə ðə meɪl ɡɹumz," tiɑnə sɛd wɪð ə snɪf. "wiv hæd tu ɡɛt wɪð tʃaɪld, jə noʊ, ən tɛn mɔɹ laɪkli tə. ðə ɡɝl nidz mɔɹ fɹɛnz, ðoʊ. fɹɛnz wɪl də ðə tʃɹɪk wɪð hɝ." ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz tu mɔɹ waɪt-klæd nɑvəsɪz hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə tɛnt, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm skwikɪŋ ən skɪɾɪŋ tə ə hɔlt wən ðeɪ faʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ stændɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. heɪstəli dʒɹɑpɪŋ kɝtsiz, ðeɪ skʌɾəld tə ðə bæk ə ðə tɛn əɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm tiɑnə ən foʊldəd ðɛɹ kloʊks ɑn ə bɛntʃ bɪfɔɹ fɛtʃɪŋ ə pɑɹtli waɪt ɡɑbləɾ ən ən ɔlmoʊst waɪt kʌp fɹəm wʌn ə ðə tʃɛsts.

Seeing the pair of them together made Egwene uneasy. "I didn't know friends were allowed in here to watch," she said. "Is Nicola still causing problems?" Nicola and Areina had attempted to blackmail her, and Myrelle and Nisao, but that was not what she meant. That was still another secret. "Better the girl's friendly with Areina than with one of the male grooms," Tiana said with a sniff. "We've had two get with child, you know, and ten more likely to. The girl needs more friends, though. Friends will do the trick with her." She cut off as two more white-clad novices hurried into the tent, the pair of them squeaking and skidding to a halt when they found Aes Sedai standing right in front of them. Hastily dropping curtsies, they scuttled to the back of the tent at a gesture from Tiana and folded their cloaks on a bench before fetching a partly white goblet and an almost white cup from one of the chests.

ʃɛɝinə sɔ ðɛm sɛɾəld tə wɝk, ðən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ oʊn kloʊk ən swʌŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ ʌp ðə tɛnt. "ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, tiɑnə sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə kɝtsi ðət dʒʌs keɪm ʃɔɹɾ ə biɪŋ tə ən ikwəl, "aɪv bɪn toʊld ɔf tə hɛlp wɪð ðə mɪddeɪ mil tədeɪ, ən aɪ wʊdnt wɑnə ɡɛt kɹɔswaɪz wɪð ðə kʊks." hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɛɡwin fəɹ ə bɹif moʊmənt, ən ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf.

Sharina saw them settled to work, then gathered her own cloak and swung it around her shoulders before coming up the tent. "If you will excuse me, Tiana Sedai," she said, making a curtsy that just came short of being to an equal, "I've been told off to help with the midday meal today, and I wouldn't want to get crosswise with the cooks." Her dark eyes rested on Egwene for a brief moment, and she nodded to herself.

"ɡoʊ ɑn, ðɛn," tiɑnə sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ wəd heɪt tə hɪɹ jə hæd bɪn swɪtʃt fəɹ biɪŋ leɪt." wɪθaʊt tɝnɪŋ ə hɛɹ, ʃɛɝinə ɔfɝɾ əɹ kɝɾəsiz əɡɛn, niðɝ ɪn ə hɝi nɔɹ dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt, tə tiɑnə, tə ðə sɪɾɝz, tə ɛɡwin - wɪð ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ðət wɑz pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ bʌt tu ʃɔɹt fəɹ əfɛns - ən wən ðə tɛntflæp swʌŋ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ, tiɑnə blu aʊɾ əɹ tʃiks ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

"Go on, then," Tiana said sharply. "I would hate to hear you had been switched for being late." Without turning a hair, Sharina offered her courtesies again, neither in a hurry nor dragging it out, to Tiana, to the Sitters, to Egwene - with another glance that was penetrating but too short for offense - and when the tentflap swung shut behind her, Tiana blew out her cheeks in exasperation.

"nɪkoʊlə kɑzəz lɛs tʃɹʌbəl ðən sʌm," ʃi sɛd dɑɹkli, ən dʒɑnjə ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"Nicola causes less trouble than some," she said darkly, and Janya shook her head.

"ʃɛɝinə dʌzn kɑz pɹɑbləmz, tiɑnə." ʃi spoʊk əz kwɪkli əz ɛvɝ, bʌt kwaɪətli, soʊ hɝ vɔɪs wəd nɑt kæɹi tə ðə bæk ə ðə tɛnt. dɪsəɡɹiməns bɪtwin sɪstɝz wɝ nɛvɝ ɛɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə nɑvəsɪz. ɪspɛʃli wən ðə dɪsəɡɹimənt wɑz oʊvɝ ə nɑvəs. "ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi noʊz ðə ɹulz bɛɾɝ ðən ɛni æksɛptɪd, ən nɛvɝ pʊts ə toʊ oʊvɝ ðə laɪn. ʃi nɛvɝ ʃɝks əɾ ivən ðə dɝɾiəst tʃɔɹz, iðɝ, ən ʃiz ðə fɝs tə lɛn ə hænd wən ənʌðɝ nɑvəs nidz wʌn. ʃɛɝinə ɪz sɪmpli hu ʃi ɪz. laɪt, jə kæn əlaʊ ə nɑvəs tə ɪntɪmɪdeɪt ju."

"Sharina doesn't cause problems, Tiana." She spoke as quickly as ever, but quietly, so her voice would not carry to the back of the tent. Disagreements between sisters were never aired in front of novices. Especially when the disagreement was over a novice. "She already knows the rules better than any Accepted, and never puts a toe over the line. She never shirks at even the dirtiest chores, either, and she's the first to lend a hand when another novice needs one. Sharina is simply who she is. Light, you can't allow a novice to intimidate you."

tiɑnə stɪfən ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, bʌt wʌns dʒɑnjə hæd ðə bɪt bɪtwin əɹ tiθ, ɡɛɾɪŋ ə wɝɾ ɪn ɛdʒwaɪz wɑz noʊ izi mæɾɝ. "nɪkoʊlə, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, kɑzəz ɔl sɔɹts ə pɹɑbləmz, mʌðɝ," ðə bɹaʊn ɹʌʃt ɑn. "ɛvɝ sɪns wi faʊn aʊt ʃiz ðə fɔɹtɛlɪŋ, ʃiz bɪn fɔɹtɛlɪŋ tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz ə deɪ, tə hɪɹ əɹ tɛl ɪt. əɹ ɹæðɝ, tə hɪɹ ɑɹinə tɛl ɪt. nɪkoʊlə ɪz smɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə noʊ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz əwɛɹ ʃi kæn ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt ʃi sɛz wən ʃi fɔɹtɛlz, bʌɾ ɑɹinə ɔlweɪz simz tə bi ðəɹ tə hɪɹ ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən hɛlp əɹ ɪntɝpɹət. səm ɑɹ ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə kæmp wɪð hæf ə bɹeɪn ən ə kɹɛdʒjələs neɪtʃɝ maɪt θɪŋk ʌv - bæɾəlz wɪð ðə sintʃæn əɹ ði æʃə'-mæn, ən æmɪɝlɪn ɪmpɹɪzənd, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn duɪŋ naɪn ɪmpɑsəbəl θɪŋz, vɪʒənz ðət maɪt bi tɑɹmən ɡdən əɹ ə bɪliəs stʌmək - ən ðə ɹɛst ɔl dʒʌs hæpən tə ɪndəkeɪt ðət nɪkoʊlə ɔt tə bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ wɪð əɹ lɛsənz. ʃiz ɔlweɪz tu ɡɹiɾi fəɹ ðæt. aɪ θɪŋk ivən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz əv stɑp bɪlivɪŋ hɝ."

Tiana stiffened and opened her mouth angrily, but once Janya had the bit between her teeth, getting a word in edgewise was no easy matter. "Nicola, on the other hand, causes all sorts of problems, Mother," the Brown rushed on. "Ever since we found out she has the Foretelling, she's been Foretelling two or three times a day, to hear her tell it. Or rather, to hear Areina tell it. Nicola is smart enough to know everyone is aware she can't remember what she says when she Foretells, but Areina always seems to be there to hear and remember, and help her interpret. Some are the sort of thing anyone in the camp with half a brain and a credulous nature might think of - battles with the Seanchan or the Asha'-man, an Amyrlin imprisoned, the Dragon Reborn doing nine impossible things, visions that might be Tarmon Gai'don or a bilious stomach - and the rest all just happen to indicate that Nicola ought to be allowed to go faster with her lessons. She's always too greedy for that. I think even most of the other novices have stopped believing her."

"ʃi ɔlsoʊ poʊks əɹ noʊz ɛvɹiwɛɹ," sæliɾə pʊɾ ɪn ðə moʊmən dʒɑnjə ɡeɪv əɹ ən oʊpənɪŋ, "hɝ ən ðə ɡɹum, boʊθ." hɝ feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð ən kul, ən ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl əz ðoʊ ðət wɝ ðə foʊkəs ə hɝ ətɛnʃən, bʌt ʃi ɹʌʃt əɹ wɝdz ə lɪɾəl, pɝhæps fɪɹɪŋ ðət ðə bɹaʊn wəd teɪk oʊvɝ əɡɛn. "ðeɪv boʊθ bɪn swɪtʃt fəɹ ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn sɪstɝz, ən aɪ maɪsɛlf kɑt nɪkoʊlə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pik ɪndə wʌn ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz. ʃi sɛd ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə si ə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn ðə wiv. ɪmpeɪʃəns, aɪ kən ʌndɝstænd, bʌt dəsit kænɑt bi tɑlɝeɪɾəd. aɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪliv nɪkoʊlə wɪl əteɪn ðə ʃɔl, ən fɹæŋkli, aɪv bɪɡʌn tə wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ʃi ʃəd bi sɛn əweɪ sun ɹæðɝ ðən leɪt. ðə nɑvəs bʊk meɪ bi oʊpən tə ɛvɹiwʌn," ʃi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs ɡlæns əɾ ɛɡwin, "bʌt wi də nɑɾ əv tə loʊɝ əɹ stændɝdz kəmplitli." ɡlɛɹɪŋ, tiɑnə pɝst əɹ lɪps stʌbɝnli, ɛmfəsaɪzɪŋ əɹ dɪmpəl əɡɛn. jə kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɛt ʃi hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl fəɹ oʊvɝ θɝɾi jɪɹz ən θɪŋk əɹ ə nɑvəs hɝsɛlf. "æz lɔŋ əz aɪm mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, ðə dɪsɪʒən ɑn wɛðɝ tə sɛn ə ɡɝl əweɪ ɪz maɪn," ʃi sɛd hiɾɪdli, "æn aɪ də nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə luz ə ɡɝl ə nɪkoʊləz pətɛnʃəl." nɪkoʊlə wəd bi vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, wʌn deɪ. "ɔɹ ʃɛɝinəz," ʃi æɾəd wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, hænz smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. ʃɛɝinəz pətɛnʃəl wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃɔɹɾ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl, fɑɹ bɪɑn ɛniwʌn ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi ɪksɛp fəɹ nɪneɪiv, ən əhɛɾ ə nɪneɪiv əz wɛl. səm θɔt ʃi maɪt bɪkʌm əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə bi, ðoʊ ðət wɑz oʊnli spɛkjəleɪʃən. "ɪf nɪkoʊlə hæz bɪn bɑðɝɪŋ ju, mʌðɝ, əl si tə hɝ."

"She also pokes her nose everywhere," Salita put in the moment Janya gave her an opening, "her and the groom, both." Her face remained smooth and cool, and she shifted her shawl as though that were the focus of her attention, but she rushed her words a little, perhaps fearing that the Brown would take over again. "They've both been switched for eavesdropping on sisters, and I myself caught Nicola trying to peek into one of the Traveling grounds. She said she just wanted to see a gateway open, but I think she was trying to learn the weave. Impatience, I can understand, but deceit cannot be tolerated. I no longer believe Nicola will attain the shawl, and frankly, I've begun to wonder whether she should be sent away soon rather than late. The novice book may be open to everyone," she finished with an expressionless glance at Egwene, "but we do not have to lower our standards completely." Glaring, Tiana pursed her lips stubbornly, emphasizing her dimple again. You could almost forget she had worn the shawl for over thirty years and think her a novice herself. "As long as I am Mistress of Novices, the decision on whether to send a girl away is mine," she said heatedly, "and I do not intend to lose a girl of Nicola's potential." Nicola would be very strong in the Power, one day. "Or Sharina's," she added with a grimace, hands smoothing her skirts in irritation. Sharina's potential was nothing short of remarkable, far beyond anyone in living memory except for Nynaeve, and ahead of Nynaeve as well. Some thought she might become as strong as it was possible to be, though that was only speculation. "If Nicola has been bothering you, Mother, I will see to her."

"aɪ wɑz dʒʌs kjʊɹiəs," ɛɡwin sɛd kɛɹfəli, swɑloʊɪŋ ə sədʒɛstʃən ðət ðə jʌŋ wʊmən ən əɹ fɹɛn boʊθ bi wɑtʃt kloʊsli. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊt nɪkoʊlə. ɪt wəd bi tu izi tə faɪn hɝsɛlf wɪð ə tʃɔɪs bɪtwin laɪɪŋ əɹ ɹɪvilɪŋ mæɾɝz ʃi dɛɹd nɑɾ ɪkspoʊz. ə pɪɾi ʃi hæd nɑɾ əlaʊd sɪuən tə ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ tu kwaɪət dɛθs.

"I was just curious," Egwene said carefully, swallowing a suggestion that the young woman and her friend both be watched closely. She did not want to talk about Nicola. It would be too easy to find herself with a choice between lying or revealing matters she dared not expose. A pity she had not allowed Siuan to arrange for two quiet deaths.

hɝ hɛd dʒɝkt ɪn ʃɑk ət ðə θɔt. hæd ʃi ɡɔn ðət fɑɹ fɹəm ɛmənz fild? ʃi nu ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɔɹɾɝ mɛn tə daɪ ɪn bæɾəl sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən ʃi θɔt ʃi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɔɹɾɝ ə dɛθ ɪf ðə nid wɑz ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf. ɪf wʌn dɛθ kəd stɑp ðə dɛθ ə θaʊzənz, əɹ ivən hʌnʒɹədz, wɑz ɪt nɑt ɹaɪt tə ɔɹɾɝ ɪt? bʌt ðə deɪnʒɝ pɹizɛntəd baɪ nɪkoʊlə ən ɑɹinə wɑz sɪmpli ðət ðeɪ maɪt ɹɪvil sikɹəts ðət kəɾ ɪnkənvinjəns ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ.

Her head jerked in shock at the thought. Had she gone that far from Emond's Field? She knew she would have to order men to die in battle sooner or later, and she thought she might be able to order a death if the need was great enough. If one death could stop the death of thousands, or even hundreds, was it not right to order it? But the danger presented by Nicola and Areina was simply that they might reveal secrets that could inconvenience Egwene al'Vere.

oʊ, maɪɹɛl ən ði ʌðɝz maɪt bi lʌki tə ɡɛɾ ɔf wɪð ə bɝtʃɪŋ, ən ðeɪ wəd sɝɾənli kənsɪɾɝ ðət mɔɹ ðən ɪnkənvinjənt, bʌt dɪskʌmfɝt, haʊɛvɝ ɡɹeɪt, wɑz nɑt səfɪʃən ɹizən fəɹ kɪlɪŋ.

Oh, Myrelle and the others might be lucky to get off with a birching, and they would certainly consider that more than inconvenient, but discomfort, however great, was not sufficient reason for killing.

əbɹʌpli, ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən tiɑnə ən ðə tu sɪɾɝz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, dʒɑnjə nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə haɪɾ əɹ kjʊɹiɑsəɾi bɪhaɪn ə mæsk ə sɝɛnəɾi. tə kʌvɝ hɝsɛlf, ɛɡwin ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fɹaʊn tə ðə teɪbəl wɛɹ kɛɹən ən æʃmɑneɪl wɝ wʌns mɔɹ ət wɝk. ðə waɪɾ ɑn æʃmɑneɪlz kʌp hæd klaɪmd ə lɪɾəl fɑɹðɝ, bʌɾ ɪn dʒʌs ðət ʃɔɹt taɪm, kɛɹən hæd kɑɾ ʌp. mɔɹ ðən kɑɾ ʌp, ɪn fækt, sɪns əɹ ɡɑblət stʊd twaɪs əz haɪ əz ðə kʌp.

Abruptly, Egwene realized that she was frowning, and Tiana and the two Sitters were watching her, Janya not bothering to hide her curiosity behind a mask of serenity. To cover herself, Egwene shifted her frown to the table where Kairen and Ashmanaille were once more at work. The white on Ashmanaille's cup had climbed a little farther, but in just that short time, Kairen had caught up. More than caught up, in fact, since her goblet stood twice as high as the cup.

"jɔɹ skɪl ɪz ɪmpɹuvɪŋ, kɛɹən," ɛɡwin sɛɾ əpɹuvɪŋli. ðə blu lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ, ən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. hɝ oʊvəl feɪs bɪkeɪm ən ɪmədʒ ə kul kɑm ɝaʊn ðoʊz aɪsi blu aɪz. "ðɛɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ skɪl ɪnvɑlvd, mʌðɝ. ɔl ðæts niɾəd ɪz tə sɛt ðə wiv ən weɪt." ðə læst wɝd hɛld ə tʌtʃ ʌv ækɹɪdnəs, ən fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə slaɪt hɛzəteɪʃən bɪfɔɹ mʌðɝ. kɛɹən hæd bɪn sɛn ɔf fɹəm sɑlədɑɹ ɑn ə vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt mɪʃən oʊnli tə si ɪt kəlæps ɪn ə ʃæmbəlz, ðoʊ fɹəm noʊ fɔlt ə hɝz, ən ʃi hæd ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛm ɪn mʊɹændi tə faɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi hæd lɛf bɪhaɪn stʊɾ ɑn ɪts hɛɾ ən ə ɡɝl ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əz ə nɑvəs wɛɹɪŋ ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl. ʌv leɪt, kɛɹən hæd bɪn spɛndɪŋ ə ɡʊd dil ə taɪm wɪð ləleɪn.

"Your skill is improving, Kairen," Egwene said approvingly. The Blue looked up at her, and drew a deep breath. Her oval face became an image of cool calm around those icy blue eyes. "There isn't much skill involved, Mother. All that's needed is to set the weave and wait." The last word held a touch of acridness, and for that matter, there had been a slight hesitation before Mother. Kairen had been sent off from Salidar on a very important mission only to see it collapse in a shambles, though from no fault of hers, and she had returned to them in Murandy to find everything she had left behind stood on its head and a girl she remembered as a novice wearing the Amyrlin's stole. Of late, Kairen had been spending a good deal of time with Lelaine.

"ʃi ɪz ɪmpɹuvɪŋ; ɪn səm θɪŋz," dʒɑnjə sɛd wɪð ə pɔɪntəd fɹaʊn fəɹ ðə blu sɪstɝ. dʒɑnjə maɪɾ əv bɪn əz ʃʊɹ əz ɛni ʌðɝ sɪɾɝ ðət ðə hɔl wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ə pʌpət wən ðeɪ ɹeɪzd ɛɡwin, bʌt ʃi sim tə hæv æksɛptɪd ðəɾ ɛɡwin dɪd wɛɹ ðə stoʊl, ən dɪzɝv ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛk fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn. "ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ daʊt ʃɪl kætʃ lin ənlɛs ʃi əplaɪz hɝsɛlf, mʌtʃ lɛs jɝsɛlf, mʌðɝ.

"She is improving; in some things," Janya said with a pointed frown for the Blue sister. Janya might have been as sure as any other Sitter that the Hall was getting a puppet when they raised Egwene, but she seemed to have accepted that Egwene did wear the stole, and deserved the proper respect from everyone. "Of course, I doubt she'll catch Leane unless she applies herself, much less yourself, Mother.

jʌŋ boʊɾuwɪn maɪt kætʃ hɝ, ɪn fækt. aɪ wʊdnt wɑnə bi aʊtdʌn baɪ ə nɑvəs, maɪsɛlf, bʌɾ aɪ səpoʊz səm doʊn fil ðət weɪ." ə steɪn ə ɹɛd kɹɛpt ɪndə kɛɹənz tʃiks, ən əɹ aɪz dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɡɑblət.

Young Bodewhin might catch her, in fact. I wouldn't want to be outdone by a novice, myself, but I suppose some don't feel that way." A stain of red crept into Kairen's cheeks, and her eyes dropped to the goblet.

tiɑnə snɪft. "boʊɾuwɪnz ə ɡʊd ɡɝl, bʌt ʃi spɛnz mɔɹ taɪm ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ən pleɪɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz ðən əplaɪɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪf ʃɑ - " ʃi ɪnheɪld ʃɑɹpli. "ɪf ʃi ɪzənt wɑtʃt. jɛstɝdeɪ, ʃi ən ælθɪn kɑnli tʃɹaɪd tu aɪɾəmz ət wʌns, dʒʌs tə si wʌt wəd hæpən, ən ðə θɪŋz fjuz təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə sɑləd lʌmp. jusləs fəɹ seɪl, ʌv kɔɹs, ənlɛs jə faɪn sʌmwʌn u wɑns ə pɛɹ ə hæf-aɪɝn, bækslæʃvtɪi-kwəndɪlɝ kʌps dʒɔɪn əɾ æŋɡəlz. ən ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt maɪɾ əv hæpən tə ðə ɡɝlz. ðeɪ dɪdn sim tə bi hɑɹmd, bʌɾ u kən seɪ əbaʊt ðə nɛks taɪm?" "meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ ɪzən ə nɛks taɪm," ɛɡwin sɛɾ æbsənli, hɝ ətɛnʃən ɑn kɛɹənz kʌp. ðə laɪn ʌv waɪt kɹɛpt ʌpwɝd stɛɾəli. wən lin dɪd ðɪs wiv, blæk aɪɝn tɝn tə waɪt kwəndɪlɝ əz ɪf ði aɪɝn wɝ sɪŋkɪŋ kwɪkli ɪndə mɪlk.

Tiana sniffed. "Bodewhin's a good girl, but she spends more time giggling and playing with the other novices than applying herself if Sha - " She inhaled sharply. "If she isn't watched. Yesterday, she and Althyn Conly tried two items at once, just to see what would happen, and the things fused together in a solid lump. Useless for sale, of course, unless you find someone who wants a pair of half-iron, \vtii-cuendillar cups joined at angles. And the Light knows what might have happened to the girls. They didn't seem to be harmed, but who can say about the next time?" "Make sure there isn't a next time," Egwene said absently, her attention on Kairen's cup. The line of white crept upward steadily. When Leane did this weave, black iron turned to white cuendillar as if the iron were sinking quickly into milk.

fəɹ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf, ðə tʃeɪnʒ wɑz fæstɝ ðən ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, blæk tə waɪɾ ɪn ə flæʃ. ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi kɛɹən ən lin, bʌɾ ivən lin wɑz bɛɹli fæst ɪnʌf. kɛɹən niɾəd taɪm tə ɪmpɹuv.

For Egwene herself, the change was faster than the blink of an eye, black to white in a flash. It would have to be Kairen and Leane, but even Leane was barely fast enough. Kairen needed time to improve.

deɪz? wiks? wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, kəz ɛniθɪŋ lɛs mɛn dɪzæstɝ, fəɹ ðə wɪmən ɪnvɑlvd ən fəɹ ðə mɛn u wəd daɪ faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən meɪbi fəɹ ðə taʊɝ. sʌɾənli ɛɡwin wɑz ɡlæd ʃi hæɾ əpɹuv bioʊnɪnz sədʒɛstʃən. tɛlɪŋ kɛɹən waɪ ʃi niɾəd tə tʃɹaɪ hɑɹɾɝ maɪɾ əv spɝɾ əɹ ɛfɝts, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ənʌðɝ sikɹət ðət hæd tə bi kɛpt əntɪl ðə taɪm keɪm tə ənveɪl ɪt tə ðə wɝld.

Days? Weeks? Whatever was necessary, because anything less meant disaster, for the women involved and for the men who would die fighting in the streets of Tar Valon and maybe for the Tower. Suddenly Egwene was glad she had approved Beonin's suggestion. Telling Kairen why she needed to try harder might have spurred her efforts, but this was another secret that had to be kept until the time came to unveil it to the world.

tʃæptɝ eɪtin

CHAPTER 18

eɪ tʃæt wɪð sɪuən deɪʃɝ hæd bɪn teɪkən əweɪ wən ɛɡwin lɛf ðə tɛnt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ði oʊpənɪŋ ə hɝ kaʊl wɝk bɛɾɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs ət meɪkɪŋ ə weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd. ʃi muvd ɪn ə ɹɪpəl ə kɝtsiz, wɪð ði əkeɪʒənəl baʊ θɹoʊn ɪn fɹəm ə wɔɹɾɝ, əɹ ə kɹæfsmən u hæd səm tæsk əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz tɛns. səm nɑvəsɪz skwikt wən ðeɪ sɔ ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl, ən hoʊl fæmliz stɛp hɝidli ɔf ðə wɔkweɪ, meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ dip kɝtsiz ɪn ðə maɪɹ ə ðə stʃɹit. sɪns ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə ɔɹɾɝ pʌnɪʃmən fəɹ səm ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪmən, wɝd hæd spɹɛɾ əmʌŋ ðə nɑvəsɪz ðət ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz sɛɝl beɪɡənd, ən ɪt wɑz bɛs tə əvɔɪɾ ɪnkɝɪŋ əɹ tɛmpɝ, wɪtʃ kəd spɹɪŋ ʌp laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ. nɑt ðət moʊst ə ðɛm nu ɪnʌf hɪstɝi tə hæv ɛni ɹil aɪdiə hu sɛɝl hæd bɪn, bʌɾ əɹ neɪm hæd bɪn ə baɪwɝɾ ʌv aɪɝn-hændəd stʃɹiknəs ɪn ðə taʊɝ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ən ði æksɛptɪd meɪd ʃʊɹ ðət nɑvəsɪz əbzɔɹb tɪdbɪts laɪk ðæt. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðəɾ ɛɡwinz kaʊl hɪɾ əɹ feɪs. baɪ ðə tɛnθ taɪm ə nɑvəs fæmli lɛpt aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ laɪk fɹaɪɾənd hɛɹz, ʃi wɑz ɡɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ tiθ soʊ hɑɹd ðət siɪŋ əɹ feɪs wʊɾə səmɛntəɾ əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ tʃuɪŋ aɪɝn ən spɪɾɪŋ neɪlz. ʃi hæd ðə hɔɹəbəl filɪŋ ðəɾ ɪn ə fju hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, æksɛptɪd wəd bi juzɪŋ əɹ neɪm tə fɹaɪɾən nɑvəsɪz ðə weɪ ðeɪ juz sɛɝlz naʊ.

A Chat with Siuan Daishar had been taken away when Egwene left the tent, of course, but the seven-striped stole hanging from the opening of her cowl worked better than an Aes Sedai's face at making a way through the crowd. She moved in a ripple of curtsies, with the occasional bow thrown in from a Warder, or a craftsman who had some task among the sister's tents. Some novices squeaked when they saw the Amyrlin's stole, and whole families stepped hurriedly off the walkway, making their deep curtsies in the mire of the street.
