Since she had been forced to order punishment for some of the Two Rivers women, word had spread among the novices that the Amyrlin was as hard as Sereille Bagand, and it was best to avoid incurring her temper, which could spring up like wildfire. Not that most of them knew enough history to have any real idea who Sereille had been, but her name had been a byword of iron-handed strictness in the Tower for a hundred years, and the Accepted made sure that novices absorbed tidbits like that. It was a good thing that Egwene's cowl hid her face. By the tenth time a novice family leaped out of her way like frightened hares, she was gritting her teeth so hard that seeing her face would have cemented her reputation for chewing iron and spitting nails. She had the horrible feeling that in a few hundred years, Accepted would be using her name to frighten novices the way they used Sereille's now.

ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ðə lɪɾəl mæɾɝ ə sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ fɝst. smɔl ɪɹɪteɪʃənz hæd tə weɪt. ʃi θɔt ʃi cʊɾə spɪt neɪlz wɪθaʊt ði aɪɝn.

Of course, there was the little matter of securing the White Tower first. Small irritations had to wait. She thought she could have spit nails without the iron.

ðə kɹaʊdz θɪn tə nʌθɪŋ ɝaʊn ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, wɪtʃ wɑz dʒʌst ə pikt kænvəs tɛnt wɪð pætʃt bɹaʊn wɔlz, dɪspaɪt ðə neɪm. laɪk ðə hɔl, ɪt wɑz ə pleɪs tə bi əvɔɪɾəd ənlɛs jə hæd bɪznəs ðəɹ əɹ wɝ sʌmənd. noʊ wʌn wɑz sɪmpli æsk tə ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ əɹ ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi. ðə moʊst ɪnɑkjuəs ɪnvɪteɪʃən tə iðɝ wɑz ə sʌmənz, ə fæk ðət tɝn ðət sɪmpəl tɛn ɪndə ə heɪvən. swipɪŋ θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi flæps, ʃi swʌŋ əɹ kloʊk ɔf wɪð ə filɪŋ ə ɹɪlif. ə pɛɹ ə bɹeɪʒɝz meɪd ðə tɛn dɪlɪʃəʃli wɔɹm æftɝ aʊtsaɪd, ən ðeɪ ɡeɪv ɔf vɛɹi lɪɾəl smoʊk. ə tʌtʃ ə swit sɛn lɪŋɡɝd fɹəm ðə dʒɹaɪɾ ɝbz ðət hæd bɪn spɹɪŋkəld ɑn ðə ɡloʊɪŋ ɛmbɝz. "ðə weɪ ðoʊz ful ɡɝlz bɪheɪv, jə wəd θɪŋk aɪ - " ʃi bɪɡæn ɪn ə ɡɹaʊl, ən kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli.

The crowds thinned to nothing around the Amyrlin's study, which was just a peaked canvas tent with patched brown walls, despite the name. Like the Hall, it was a place to be avoided unless you had business there or were summoned. No one was simply asked to the Hall of the Tower or the Amyrlin's study. The most innocuous invitation to either was a summons, a fact that turned that simple tent into a haven. Sweeping through the entry flaps, she swung her cloak off with a feeling of relief. A pair of braziers made the tent deliciously warm after outside, and they gave off very little smoke. A touch of sweet scent lingered from the dried herbs that had been sprinkled on the glowing embers. "The way those fool girls behave, you would think I - " she began in a growl, and cut off abruptly.

ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪz tə si sɪuən stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ɪn pleɪn blu wʊl, faɪnli kʌt bʌt sɪmpəl, ə waɪd tuldliðɝ foʊldɝ hɛl tə hɝ tʃɛst. moʊst sɪstɝz stɪl sim tə bɪliv, laɪk dɛlænə, ðət ʃi wɑz ɹədus tə ɪnstʃɹʌktɪŋ ɛɡwin ɪn pɹoʊɾəkɑl ən ɹʌnɪŋ ɛɹənz, ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli ɪn boʊθ keɪsəz, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz ðəɹ bɹaɪɾ ən ɝli, wɪtʃ sim tə hæv ɡɔn ənnoʊɾɪst soʊ fɑɹ. sɪuən hæd bɪn ən æmɪɝlɪn u tʃuɾ aɪɝn, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn wəd bɪliv u dɪd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ. nɑvəsɪz pɔɪntəɾ əɹ aʊɾ əz ɔfən əz ðeɪ dɪd lin, bʌt wɪð ən ɛɹ ə daʊt ðət ʃi ɹɪli wɑz u ðə sɪstɝz sɛd. pɹɪɾi, ɪf nɑt kwaɪt bjuɾəfəl, wɪð ə dɛləkət maʊθ ən dɑɹk ɡlɔsi hɛɹ tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, sɪuən lʊkt ivən jʌŋɡɝ ðən lin, oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɛɡwin. ʃi cʊɾə bɪn teɪkən fəɹ wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd wɪθaʊt ðə blufɹɪnd ʃɔl dʒɹeɪpt əkɹɔs əɹ ɑɹmz. ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi nɛvɝ wɛnt wɪθaʊt ðə ʃɔl, tə əvɔɪɾ ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ mɪsteɪks. hɝ aɪz hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ɛni mɔɹ ðən əɹ spɪɹət, haʊɛvɝ, ən ðeɪ wɝ aɪsi blu ɔlz eɪmd ət ðə wʊmən huz pɹɛzəns wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz. hɑlimə wɑz sɝɾənli wɛlkəm, jɛɾ ɛɡwin hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə si hɝ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɑn ðə bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd kʊʃənz ðət wɝ paɪld əlɔŋ wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə tɛnt, hɝ hɛd pɹɑpt ɑn wʌn hæn eɪ si eɪtʃ eɪ ti dʌbəlju aɪ ti eɪtʃ ɛs aɪ ju eɪ ɛn fɔɹhʌnʒɹədθɝdisɛvən wɛɹ sɪuən wɑz pɹɪɾi, ðə sɔɹɾ ə jʌŋ wʊmən - simɪŋli jʌŋ, ət list - hu meɪd mɛn ən wɪmən əlaɪk smaɪl ət hɝ, hɑlimə wɑz stʌnɪŋ, wɪð bɪɡ ɡɹin aɪz ɪn ə pɝfək feɪs ən ə fʊl fɝm bʊzəm, ðə sɔɹɾ u meɪd mɛn swɑloʊ ən ʌðɝ wɪmən fɹaʊn. nɑt ðəɾ ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, əɹ bɪliv ðə teɪlz kæɹid baɪ wɪmən dʒɛləs ə ðə weɪ hɑlimə ətʃɹæktəd mɛn dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ. ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt, æftɝ ɔl. bʌɾ ivən ɪf əɹ pəzɪʃən əz dɛlænəz sɛkɹətɛɹi wɑz pleɪnli ə mæɾɝ ə tʃɛɹɪɾi baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ - ə pʊɹli ɛdʒəkeɪɾəd kʌntʃɹi wʊmən, hɑlimə fɔɹmd əɹ lɛɾɝz wɪð ði ɔkwɝdnəs ʌv ə jʌŋ tʃaɪld - dɛlænə juʒəwəli kɛpt əɹ bɪzi ɔl deɪ wɪð səm sɔɹɾ ə meɪk-wɝk. ʃi sɛldəm əpɪɹd bɪfɔɹ taɪm fəɹ bɛd, ən ðən ɪt wɑz nɪɹli ɔlweɪz kəz ʃi hæd hɝɾ ɛɡwin hæd wʌn ə hɝ hɛdz. naɪsaʊ kəd də nʌθɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz hɛdeɪks, ivən juzɪŋ ðə nu hilɪŋ, bʌt hɑliməz məsɑʒɪz wɝkt wʌndɝz ivən wən ðə peɪn hæɾ ɛɡwin wɪmpɝɪŋ.

She was not surprised to see Siuan standing beside the writing table in plain blue wool, finely cut but simple, a wide tooledleather folder held to her chest. Most sisters still seemed to believe, like Delana, that she was reduced to instructing Egwene in protocol and running errands, grudgingly in both cases, but she was always there bright and early, which seemed to have gone unnoticed so far. Siuan had been an Amyrlin who chewed iron, though no one would believe who did not already know. Novices pointed her out as often as they did Leane, but with an air of doubt that she really was who the sisters said. Pretty, if not quite beautiful, with a delicate mouth and dark glossy hair to her shoulders, Siuan looked even younger than Leane, only a few years older than Egwene. She could have been taken for one of the Accepted without the bluefringed shawl draped across her arms. That was why she never went without the shawl, to avoid embarrassing mistakes. Her eyes had not changed any more than her spirit, however, and they were icy blue awls aimed at the woman whose presence was a surprise. Halima was certainly welcome, yet Egwene had not expected to see her stretched out on the brightly colored cushions that were piled along one side of the tent, her head propped on one hand.< A C H A T W I T H S I U A N 437 Where Siuan was pretty, the sort of young woman - seemingly young, at least - who made men and women alike smile at her, Halima was stunning, with big green eyes in a perfect face and a full firm bosom, the sort who made men swallow and other women frown. Not that Egwene frowned, or believed the tales carried by women jealous of the way Halima attracted men just by being. She could not help the way she looked, after all. But even if her position as Delana's secretary was plainly a matter of charity by the Gray sister - a poorly educated country woman, Halima formed her letters with the awkwardness of a young child - Delana usually kept her busy all day with some sort of make-work. She seldom appeared before time for bed, and then it was nearly always because she had heard Egwene had one of her heads. Nisao could do nothing with those headaches, even using the new Healing, but Halima's massages worked wonders even when the pain had Egwene whimpering.

"aɪ toʊld əɹ jə wʊdn əv taɪm fəɹ vɪzəts ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, mʌðɝ," sɪuən sɛd ʃɑɹpli, stɪl ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wʊmən ɑn ðə kʊʃənz əz ʃi tʊk ɛɡwinz kloʊk wɪð əɹ fɹi hænd, "bʌɾ aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv pleɪd kæts kɹeɪɾəl wɪð maɪsɛlf əz oʊpən maɪ maʊθ." hæŋɪŋ ðə kloʊk ɑn ðə ɹʌstɪk kloʊk stænd, ʃi snɔɹɾɪd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "meɪbi ɪf aɪ wɔɹ bɹitʃɪz ən hæɾ ə mʌstæʃ, ʃid peɪ maɪnd." sɪuən sim tə bɪliv ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə ɹumɝz əbaʊt hɑliməz səpoʊz dɛpɹədeɪʃənz əmʌŋ ðə pɹɪɾiɝ kɹæfsmən ən soʊlʒɝz.

"I told her you wouldn't have time for visits this morning, Mother," Siuan said sharply, still glaring at the woman on the cushions as she took Egwene's cloak with her free hand, "but I might as well have played cat's cradle with myself as opened my mouth." Hanging the cloak on the rustic cloak stand, she snorted contemptuously. "Maybe if I wore breeches and had a mustache, she'd pay mind." Siuan seemed to believe every one of the rumors about Halima's supposed depredations among the prettier craftsmen and soldiers.

stʃɹeɪnʒli, hɑlimə simd əmjuz baɪ hɝ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. ʃi maɪɾ ivən əv ɛndʒɔɪɾ ɪt. ʃi læft, loʊ ən θɹoʊɾi, ən stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ðə kʊʃənz laɪk ə kæt. ʃi dɪɾ əv ən ənfɔɹtʃənət laɪkɪŋ fəɹ loʊ-kʌt bɑɾɪsɪz, ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ, ən ʃi nɪɹli keɪm aʊɾ ə hɝ blu-slæʃt ɡɹin sɪlk. sɪlk wɑz hɑɹdli ðə juʒəwəl ɡɑɹb fəɹ ə sɛkɹətɛɹi, bʌt dɛlænəz tʃɛɹɪɾi ɹæn dip, əɹ əɹ dɛt tə hɑlimə dɪd.

Strangely, Halima seemed amused by her reputation. She might even have enjoyed it. She laughed, low and throaty, and stretched on the cushions like a cat. She did have an unfortunate liking for low-cut bodices, incredible in this weather, and she nearly came out of her blue-slashed green silk. Silk was hardly the usual garb for a secretary, but Delana's charity ran deep, or her debt to Halima did.

"ju simd wɝid ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, mʌðɝ," ðə ɡɹin-aɪd wʊmən mɝmɝd, "æn jə slɪpt aʊt soʊ ɝli fəɹ jəɹ ɹaɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə weɪk mi. aɪ θɔt jə maɪt laɪk tə tɔk. jə wʊdnt ɡɛt soʊ mɛni hɛdeɪks ɪf jə tɔkt oʊvɝ jəɹ wɝiz mɔɹ. ət lis jə noʊ jə kən tɔk tə mi." aɪɪŋ sɪuən, hu wɑz piɹɪŋ daʊn əɹ noʊz dɪsdeɪnfəli, hɑlimə ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ smoʊki læf. "æn jə noʊ aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm ju, ənlaɪk sʌm." sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn, ən dɪlɪbɝətli bɪzid hɝsɛlf wɪð pleɪsɪŋ ðə foʊldɝ ɑn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl dʒʌst soʊ bɪtwin ðə stoʊn ɪŋkwɛl ən ðə sæn dʒɑɹ.

"You seemed worried this morning, Mother," the green-eyed woman murmured, "and you slipped out so early for your ride, trying not to wake me. I thought you might like to talk. You wouldn't get so many headaches if you talked over your worries more. At least you know you can talk to me." Eyeing Siuan, who was peering down her nose disdainfully, Halima gave another smoky laugh. "And you know I don't want anything from you, unlike some." Siuan snorted again, and deliberately busied herself with placing the folder on the writing table just so between the stone inkwell and the sand jar.

ʃi ivən fɪɾəld wɪð ðə pɛn-ɹɛst. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ɛɡwin mænədʒ nɑt tə saɪ. dʒʌst. hɑlimə dɪɾ æsk fəɹ nʌθɪŋ bɪɑn ə pæləɾ ɪn ɛɡwinz tɛnt, soʊ ʃi kəd bi ɑn hænd wən wʌn ʌv ɛɡwinz hɛdeɪks keɪm ɑn, ən slipɪŋ ðəɹ mʌst əv ɡɪvən dɪfəkəltiz wɪð kæɹiɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ duɾiz fəɹ dɛlænə.

She even fiddled with the pen-rest. With an effort, Egwene managed not to sigh. Just. Halima did ask for nothing beyond a pallet in Egwene's tent, so she could be on hand when one of Egwene's headaches came on, and sleeping there must have given difficulties with carrying out her duties for Delana.

bɪsaɪdz, ɛɡwin laɪkt əɹ ɝθi aʊtspoʊkən mænɝ. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi izi tə tɔk tə hɑlimə ən fɝɡɛt fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl ðət ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ə ɹilækseɪʃən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv ivən wɪð sɪuən. ʃi hæd fɔt tu hɑɹd fəɹ ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æmɪɝlɪn, ən əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn ðət ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən wɑz tu tɛnjəwəs. ɛvɹi slɪp fɹəm biɪŋ æmɪɝlɪn wəd meɪk ðə nɛkst slɪp iziɝ, ən ðə nɛkst, ən ðə nɛkst æftɝ ðæt, əntɪl ʃi wɑz bæk tə biɪŋ ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz ə tʃaɪld ət pleɪ. ðət meɪd hɑlimə ə lʌɡʒɝi tə bi tʃɹɛʒɝd kwaɪɾ əpɑɹt fɹəm wʌɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz kəd də tə ɛɡwinz hɛdeɪks. tə hɝ ənɔɪəns, ðoʊ, ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʊmən ɪn ðə kæmp əpɪɹd tə ʃɛɹ sɪuənz vju, wɪð ðə pɑsəbəl ɪksɛpʃən ə dɛlænə. ðə ɡɹeɪ sim tu pɹuɾɪʃ tə ɛmplɔɪ ə laɪtskɝt, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt tʃɛɹɪɾi ʃi θɔt ʃi oʊd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən tʃeɪs mɛn, əɹ ivən tʃɹɪpt əm ʌp, wɑz bɪsaɪd ðə pɔɪnt naʊ.

Besides, Egwene liked her earthy outspoken manner. It was very easy to talk to Halima and forget for a little while that she was the Amyrlin Seat, a relaxation she could not have even with Siuan. She had fought too hard for recognition as Aes Sedai and Amyrlin, and her grip on that recognition was too tenuous. Every slip from being Amyrlin would make the next slip easier, and the next, and the next after that, until she was back to being regarded as a child at play. That made Halima a luxury to be treasured quite apart from what her fingers could do to Egwene's headaches. To her annoyance, though, every other woman in the camp appeared to share Siuan's view, with the possible exception of Delana. The Gray seemed too prudish to employ a lightskirt, no matter what charity she thought she owed. In any case, whether the woman chased men, or even tripped them up, was beside the point now.

"aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ də hæv wɝk, hɑlimə," ʃi sɛd, tʌɡɪŋ ɔf əɹ ɡlʌvz. ə maʊntən ʌv wɝk, moʊs deɪz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə ʃɛɹiəmz ɹɪpɔɹts ɑn ðə teɪbəl jɛt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi wəd bi sɛndɪŋ əm sun, əlɔŋ wɪð ə fju pətɪʃənz ʃi θɔt mɛɹɪɾɪd ɛɡwinz ətɛnʃən. dʒʌst ə fju; tɛn əɹ twɛlv əpilz fəɹ ɹɪdʒɹɛs ʌv ɡɹivənsəz, wɪð ɛɡwin ɪkspɛktəd tə pæs ði æmɪɝlɪnz dʒʌdʒmən ɑn itʃ. jə kəd nɑt də ðət wɪθaʊt stʌɾi, ən kwɛstʃənz, nɑɾ ən hæn daʊn ə dʒʌs dɪsɪʒən. "pɝhæps jə kən əv dɪnɝ wɪð mi." ɪf ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɪn taɪm tə də mɔɹ ðən iɾ əɾ əɹ teɪbəl ɹaɪt ðəɹ ɪn əɹ stʌɾi. ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn təwɔɹd mɪddeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi. "wi kən tɔk ðɛn."

"I'm afraid I do have work, Halima," she said, tugging off her gloves. A mountain of work, most days. There was no sign of Sheriam's reports on the table yet, of course, but she would be sending them soon, along with a few petitions she thought merited Egwene's attention. Just a few; ten or twelve appeals for redress of grievances, with Egwene expected to pass the Amyrlin's judgment on each. You could not do that without study, and questions, not and hand down a just decision. "Perhaps you can have dinner with me." If she finished in time to do more than eat at her table right there in her study. It was getting on toward midday already. "We can talk then."

hɑlimə sæɾ ʌp əbɹʌpli, aɪz flæʃɪŋ ən fʊl lɪps kəmpɹɛst, bʌɾ əɹ skaʊl vænɪʃt əz kwɪkli əz ɪt hæd kʌm. ə smoʊldɝɪŋ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ. hæd ʃi bɪn ə kæt, ʃi wʊɾə hæɾ əɹ bæk ɑɹtʃt ən əɹ teɪl laɪk ə bɑɾəl-bɹʌʃ. ɹaɪzɪŋ ɡɹeɪsfəli tə hɝ fiɾ ɑn ðə leɪɝd kɑɹpəts, ʃi smuðd əɹ dʒɹɛs oʊvɝ əɹ hɪps. "vɛɹi wɛl, ðɛn. ɪf jəɹ sɝɾən jə doʊnt wɑn mi tə steɪ." wɪð ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl taɪmɪŋ, ə dʌl θɹəb bɪɡæn bɪhaɪn ɛɡwinz aɪz, ən ɔl tu fəmɪljɝ pɹikɝsɝ tə ə blaɪndɪŋ hɛdeɪk, bʌt ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɛniweɪ ən ɹɪpiɾɪd ðət ʃi hæd wɝk tə du. hɑlimə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, hɝ maʊθ ɡoʊɪŋ taɪt wʌns mɔɹ, hænz fɪstɪŋ ɪn əɹ skɝts, ðən ʃi snætʃt əɹ fɝ-laɪn sɪlk kloʊk fɹəm ðə kloʊk stæn ən stɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt wɪθaʊt bɑðɝɪŋ tə pʊl ðə ɡɑɹmən ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi kəd də hɝsɛlf ən ɪnʒɝi ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt laɪk ðəɾ ɪn ðə koʊld.

Halima sat up abruptly, eyes flashing and full lips compressed, but her scowl vanished as quickly as it had come. A smoldering remained in her eyes, though. Had she been a cat, she would have had her back arched and her tail like a bottle-brush. Rising gracefully to her feet on the layered carpets, she smoothed her dress over her hips. "Very well, then. If you're certain you don't want me to stay." With remarkable timing, a dull throb began behind Egwene's eyes, an all too familiar precursor to a blinding headache, but she shook her head anyway and repeated that she had work to do. Halima hesitated a moment longer, her mouth going tight once more, hands fisting in her skirts, then she snatched her fur-lined silk cloak from the cloak stand and stalked out of the tent without bothering to pull the garment around her shoulders. She could do herself an injury going about like that in the cold.

"ðæt fɪʃwaɪf tɛmpɝ wɪl ɡɛɾ əɹ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ," sɪuən mʌɾɝd bɪfɔɹ ði ɛntʃɹi flæps stɑp sweɪɪŋ. skaʊlɪŋ æftɝ hɑlimə, ʃi twɪtʃt əɹ ʃɔl ʌp ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. "ðə wʊmən hoʊlz ɪɾ ɪn ɝaʊn ju, bʌt ʃi dʌzn maɪnd ɡɪvɪŋ mi ðə ɹʌf saɪɾ ə hɝ tʌŋ. mi əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. ʃiz bɪn hɝd skɹimɪŋ ət dɛlænə. hu ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə sɛkɹətɛɹi skɹimɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɛmplɔɪɝ, ən ə sɪstɝ ət ðæt? eɪ sɪɾɝ! aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd waɪ dɛlænə pʊts ʌp wɪð hɝ."

"That fishwife temper will get her in trouble sooner or later," Siuan muttered before the entry flaps stopped swaying. Scowling after Halima, she twitched her shawl up onto her shoulders. "The woman holds it in around you, but she doesn't mind giving me the rough side of her tongue. Me or anybody else. She's been heard screaming at Delana. Who ever heard of a secretary screaming at her employer, and a sister at that? A Sitter! I don't understand why Delana puts up with her."

"ðæts dɛlænəz bɪznəs, ʃʊɹli." kwɛstʃənɪŋ ənʌðɝ sɪstɝz ækʃənz wɑz dʒʌst əz fɔɹbɪɾən əz ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. oʊnli baɪ kʌstəm, nɑt lɔ, jɛt səm kʌstəmz wɝ əz stʃɹɔŋ əz lɔ. ʃʊɹli ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə ɹimaɪn sɪuən ə ðæt.

"That's Delana's business, surely." Questioning another sister's actions was just as forbidden as interfering with them. Only by custom, not law, yet some customs were as strong as law. Surely she did not have to remind Siuan of that.

ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tɛmpəlz, ɛɡwin sæt daʊn kɛɹfəli ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, bʌt ðə tʃɛɹ wɑbəld ɛniweɪ. dɪzaɪn tə foʊl fəɹ stɔɹədʒ ɑn ə wæɡən, ðə lɛɡz hæɾ ə hæbəɾ ə foʊldɪŋ wən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt səpoʊz tə, ən nʌn ə ðə kɑɹpəntɝz hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə fɪks əm æftɝ ɹɪpiɾɪd ətɛmps.

Rubbing her temples, Egwene sat down carefully in the chair behind her writing table, but the chair wobbled anyway. Designed to fold for storage on a wagon, the legs had a habit of folding when they were not supposed to, and none of the carpenters had been able to fix them after repeated attempts.

ðə teɪbəl foʊldəɾ əz wɛl, bʌt ðət hɛld ʌp mɔɹ fɝmli. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd teɪkən ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə əkwaɪɝ ə nu tʃɛɹ ɪn mʊɹændi, jɛt ðəɹ hæd bɪn soʊ mɛni θɪŋz ðət niɾəd baɪɪŋ ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf kɔɪn tə stʃɹɛtʃ wən ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ ə tʃɛɹ. ət list ʃi hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə pɛɹ ə stænd-læmps ən ə teɪbəl-læmp, ɔl θɹi pleɪn ɹɛd-peɪntəɾ aɪɝn bʌt wɪð ɡʊd mɪɹɝz ðət wɝ fɹi ʌv bʌbəlz. ɡʊd laɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə hɛlp əɹ hɛdeɪks, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹid baɪ ə fju tæloʊ kændəlz ən ə læntɝn.

The table folded as well, but that held up more firmly. She wished she had taken the opportunity to acquire a new chair in Murandy, yet there had been so many things that needed buying and not enough coin to stretch when she already had a chair. At least she had acquired a pair of stand-lamps and a table-lamp, all three plain red-painted iron but with good mirrors that were free of bubbles. Good light did not seem to help her headaches, yet it was better than trying to read by a few tallow candles and a lantern.

ɪf sɪuən hɝɾ ɛni ɹibjuk, ɪt dɪd nɑt sloʊ hɝ daʊn. "ɪts mɔɹ ðən dʒʌst ə tɛmpɝ. wʌns əɹ twaɪs, aɪv θɔt ʃi wɑz ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʃɹaɪk mi. aɪ səpoʊz ʃiz sɛns ɪnʌf tə hoʊl bæk fɹəm ðæt, bʌt nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪm kənvɪnst ʃi mænədʒ tə bɹeɪk ə wilɹaɪts ɑɹm sʌmhaʊ. hi sɛz i fɛl, bʌɾ i lʊks tə bi laɪɪŋ tə mi, wɪð ɪz aɪz ʃɪftɪŋ ən ɪz maʊθ twɪtʃɪŋ.

If Siuan heard any rebuke, it did not slow her down. "It's more than just a temper. Once or twice, I've thought she was on the brink of trying to strike me. I suppose she has sense enough to hold back from that, but not everyone is Aes Sedai. I'm convinced she managed to break a wheelwright's arm somehow. He says he fell, but he looks to be lying to me, with his eyes shifting and his mouth twitching.

hi wʊdn laɪk ædmɪɾɪŋ ə wʊmən bɛn ɪz ɛlboʊ bækwɝdz, naʊ wəd hi?"

He wouldn't like admitting a woman bent his elbow backwards, now would he?"

"ɡɪv oʊvɝ, sɪuən," ɛɡwin sɛd wɛɹəli. "ðə mæn laɪkli tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk lɪbɝɾiz." hi mʌs hæv.

"Give over, Siuan," Egwene said wearily. "The man likely tried to take liberties." He must have.

ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ hɑlimə cʊɾə bɹoʊkən ə mænz ɑɹm ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. haʊɛvɝ jə dɪskɹaɪb ðə wʊmən, mʌskjəlɝ dɪd nɑt kʌm ɪndə ɪt. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv oʊpənɪŋ ði ɪmbɔs foʊldɝ ðət sɪuən hæd leɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ʃi ɹɛstəɾ əɹ hænz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ðət kɛpt əm əweɪ fɹəm əɹ hɛd. meɪbi ɪf ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə peɪn, ɪt wəd ɡoʊ əweɪ ðɪs taɪm. bɪsaɪdz, fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, ʃi hæɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə ʃɛɹ wɪð sɪuən. "ɪt simz ðət səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɪleɪɾə," ʃi bɪɡæn.

She could not see how Halima could have broken a man's arm in any event. However you described the woman, muscular did not come into it. Instead of opening the embossed folder that Siuan had laid on the table, she rested her hands on either side of it. That kept them away from her head. Maybe if she ignored the pain, it would go away this time. Besides, for a change, she had information to share with Siuan. "It seems that some of the Sitters are talking about negotiating with Elaida," she began.

ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, sɪuən bæləns hɝsɛlf ətɑp wʌn ə ðə tu ɹɪkəɾi θɹi-lɛɡəd stulz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə teɪbəl ən lɪsən ətɛntɪvli, oʊnli hɝ fɪŋɡɝz muvɪŋ, laɪtli stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ skɝts, əntɪl ɛɡwin fɪnɪʃt. ðən ʃi meɪd fɪsts ən ɡɹaʊld ə sɛɾ ə kɝsɪz ðət wɝ pʌnʒənt ivən fəɹ hɝ, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ə wɪʃ fəɹ ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm tə tʃoʊk tə dɛθ ɑn wik-oʊl fɪʃ ɡʌts ən slaɪɾɪŋ daʊnhɪl fæs fɹəm ðɛɹ. kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət jʌŋ, pɹɪɾi feɪs oʊnli meɪɾ əm wɝs.

Expressionless, Siuan balanced herself atop one of the two rickety three-legged stools in front of the table and listened attentively, only her fingers moving, lightly stroking against her skirts, until Egwene finished. Then she made fists and growled a set of curses that were pungent even for her, beginning with a wish for the lot of them to choke to death on week-old fish guts and sliding downhill fast from there. Coming from that young, pretty face only made them worse.

"aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ ɹaɪt lɛɾɪŋ ɪt ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd," ʃi mʌɾɝd wʌns əɹ ɪnvɛktɪv ɹæn daʊn. "ðə tɔk wɪl spɹɛd, naʊ ɪts bɪɡʌn, ən ðɪs weɪ, jə ɡeɪn ə dʒʌmp ɑn ɪt. bioʊnɪn ʃʊdn sɝpɹaɪz mi, aɪ səpoʊz. bioʊnɪnz æmbɪʃəs, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ʃiɾ əv ɡɔn skɝiɪŋ bæk tə ɪleɪɾə ɪf ʃɛɹiəm ən ði ʌðɝz hædn stɪfən əɹ bækboʊn." vɔɪs kwɪkənɪŋ, sɪuən fɪkst əɹ aɪz ɑn ɛɡwin əz ɪf tə lɛnd weɪt tə hɝ wɝdz. "aɪ wɪʃ vɛɹɪlɪn ən ðət lɑt sɝpɹaɪz mi, mʌðɝ. dɪskaʊntɪŋ ðə blu, sɪks sɪɾɝz fɹəm faɪv ədʒəz flɛd ðə taʊɝ æftɝ ɪleɪɾə kæɹiɾ aʊɾ əɹ ku," hɝ maʊθ twɪstəd slaɪtli ɑn ðə wɝd, "æn hɪɹ wɪv wʌn fɹəm itʃ ə ðoʊz faɪv. aɪ wɑz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd læs naɪt, ɪn ðə taʊɝ - "

"I suppose you're right letting it go forward," she muttered once her invective ran down. "The talk will spread, now it's begun, and this way, you gain a jump on it. Beonin shouldn't surprise me, I suppose. Beonin's ambitious, but I always thought she'd have gone scurrying back to Elaida if Sheriam and the others hadn't stiffened her backbone." Voice quickening, Siuan fixed her eyes on Egwene as if to lend weight to her words. "I wish Varilin and that lot surprised me, Mother. Discounting the Blue, six Sitters from five Ajahs fled the Tower after Elaida carried out her coup," her mouth twisted slightly on the word, "and here we have one from each of those five. I was in Tel'aran'rhiod last night, in the Tower - "

"aɪ hoʊp jə wɝ kɛɹfəl," ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. sɪuən hɑɹdli sim tə noʊ ðə minɪŋ ə kɛɹfəl, səmtaɪmz. ðə fju dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn ðɛɹ pəzɛʃən hæd laɪnz ə sɪstɝz pæntɪŋ tə juz ðɛm, moʊsli tə vɪzət ðə taʊɝ, ən waɪl sɪuən wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli fɔɹbɪɾən wʌn, ɪt wɑz ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə. ʃi cʊɾə pʊɾ əɹ neɪm daʊn fɝɛvɝ wɪθaʊt ðə hɔl ɡɹæntɪŋ əɹ ə sɪŋɡəl naɪt. kwaɪɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə sɪstɝz u bleɪm sɪuən fəɹ ðə taʊɝ biɪŋ bɹoʊkən ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs - ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æksɛptɪd bæk kwaɪɾ əz wɔɹmli əz lin, ɑn ðəɾ əkaʊnt, nɔɹ kɑstɪd baɪ ɛniwʌn - kwaɪɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, tu mɛni ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ ɹʌf titʃɪŋ, wən ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju hu nu haʊ tə juz ðə dʒɹim tɛɹæŋɡɹil. sɪuən dɪd nɑt sʌfɝ fulz ɡlædli, ən ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ə ful ðɛɹ fɝs fju taɪmz ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, soʊ naʊ ʃi hæd tə bɑɹoʊ linz tɝn wən ʃi wɑntəd tə vɪzət ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, ən ɪf ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ sɔ hɝ ðɛɹ, 'ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə' maɪt bɪkʌm ən aʊtʃɹaɪt bæn. əɹ wɝs, sɛɾ ɔf ə sɝtʃ fəɹ u hæd loʊn əɹ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, wɪtʃ maɪɾ ɛn baɪ ənmæskɪŋ lin.

"I hope you were careful," Egwene said sharply. Siuan hardly seemed to know the meaning of careful, sometimes. The few dream ter'angreal in their possession had lines of sisters panting to use them, mostly to visit the Tower, and while Siuan was not precisely forbidden one, it was the next thing to. She could have put her name down forever without the Hall granting her a single night. Quite aside from the sisters who blamed Siuan for the Tower being broken in the first place - she was not accepted back quite as warmly as Leane, on that account, nor cosseted by anyone - quite aside from that, too many remembered her rough teaching, when she was one of the few who knew how to use the dream ter'angreal. Siuan did not suffer fools gladly, and everyone was a fool their first few times in Tel'aran'rhiod, so now she had to borrow Leane's turn when she wanted to visit the World of Dreams, and if another sister saw her there, 'the next thing to' might become an outright ban. Or worse, set off a search for who had loaned her a ter'angreal, which might end by unmasking Leane.

"ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd," sɪuən sɛd wɪð ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ, "ɪm ə dɪfɹənt wʊmən ɪn ə dɪfɹən dʒɹɛs ɛvɹi taɪm aɪ tɝn ə kɔɹnɝ." ðət wɑz ɡʊd tə hɪɹ, ðoʊ ɪt sim laɪkli ə læk ə kəntʃɹoʊl hæɾ əz mʌtʃ tə də wɪð ɪɾ əz ɪntɛnt. sɪuənz bɪlif ɪn əɹ oʊn əbɪləɾiz wɑz səmtaɪmz ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən wɔɹəntɪd.

"In Tel'aran'rhiod," Siuan said with a dismissive gesture, "I'm a different woman in a different dress every time I turn a corner." That was good to hear, though it seemed likely a lack of control had as much to do with it as intent. Siuan's belief in her own abilities was sometimes greater than warranted.

"ðə pɔɪn ɪz, læs naɪɾ aɪ sɔ ə pɑɹʃəl lɪst ə sɪɾɝz ən mænədʒ tə ɹid moʊst ə ðə neɪmz bɪfɔɹ ɪt tʃeɪnʒd tə ə tæli ʌv waɪnz." ðət wɑz ə kɑmən əkɝəns ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, wɛɹ nʌθɪŋ steɪd ðə seɪm fəɹ lɔŋ ənlɛs ɪt wɑz ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə sʌmθɪŋ pɝmənən ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. "ændaɪə fɔɹ wɑz ɹeɪz fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪ, ɹinə hæfdən fəɹ ðə ɡɹin, ən dʒuleɪn mədoʊm fəɹ ðə bɹaʊn. nʌn əz wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl mɔɹ ðən sɛvənti jɪɹz ət moʊst. ɪleɪɾə hæz ðə seɪm pɹɑbləm wi du, mʌðɝ."

"The point is, last night I saw a partial list of Sitters and managed to read most of the names before it changed to a tally of wines." That was a common occurrence in Tel'aran'rhiod, where nothing stayed the same for long unless it was a reflection of something permanent in the waking world. "Andaya Forae was raised for the Gray, Rina Hafden for the Green, and Juilaine Madome for the Brown. None has worn the shawl more than seventy years at most. Elaida has the same problem we do, Mother."

"aɪ si," ɛɡwin sɛd sloʊli. ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz məsɑʒɪŋ ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ðə θɹəb bɪhaɪn əɹ aɪz biɾ ɑn. ɪt wəd ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd. baɪ naɪtfɔl, ʃi wɑz gɑnə ɹəɡɹɛt hævɪŋ sɛn hɑlimə əweɪ. bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hæn daʊn fɝmli, ʃi muv ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ə hæf ɪntʃ tə ðə lɛft, ðən slɪɾ ɪt bæk. "wʌɾ ə ðə ɹɛst? ðeɪ hæd sɪks sɪɾɝz tə ɹipleɪs."

"I see," Egwene said slowly. She realized that she was massaging the side of her head. The throb behind her eyes beat on. It would grow stronger. It always did. By nightfall, she was going to regret having sent Halima away. Bringing her hand down firmly, she moved the leather folder in front of her a half inch to the left, then slid it back. "What of the rest? They had six Sitters to replace."

"fɛɹən nhɝən wɑz ɹeɪz fəɹ ðə waɪt," sɪuən ədmɪɾəd, "æn swænə dʒɹeɪɡən fəɹ ðə jɛloʊ.

"Ferane Neheran was raised for the White," Siuan admitted, "and Suana Dragand for the Yellow.

ðeɪv boʊθ bɪn ɪn ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pɑɹʃəl lɪst, ən aɪ dɪdnt ɡɛt tə ɹiɾ ɪɾ ɔl." hɝ bæk stʃɹeɪɾənd, ən əɹ tʃɪn ʃɑɾ aʊt stʌbɝnli. "wʌn əɹ tu ɹeɪz bɪfɔɹ taɪm wəd bi ənjuʒəwəl ɪnʌf - ɪt hæpənz, bʌt nɑɾ ɔfən - bʌt ðɪs meɪks ɪlɛvən - meɪbi twɛlv, bʌɾ ɪlɛvən fəɹ ʃʊɹ -  bɪtwin əs ən ðə taʊɝ. aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪn koʊɪnsəɾənsɪz ðət bɪɡ. wən ðə fɪʃmɑŋɡɝz ɑɹ ɔl baɪɪŋ ət ðə seɪm pɹaɪs, jə kən bɛt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə seɪm ɪn læs naɪt." "ju doʊn əv tə kənvɪns mi ɛni mɔɹ, sɪuən." wɪð ə saɪ, ɛɡwin sæt bæk, ɔɾəmætɪkli kætʃɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ lɛɡ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə foʊld wən ʃi dɪd ðæt. klɪɹli, sʌmθɪŋ ɑd wɑz hæpənɪŋ, bʌt wʌɾ ɪt min?

They've both been in the Hall before. It was only a partial list, and I didn't get to read it all." Her back straightened, and her chin shot out stubbornly. "One or two raised before time would be unusual enough - it happens, but not often - but this makes eleven - maybe twelve, but eleven for sure -  between us and the Tower. I don't believe in coincidences that big. When the fishmongers are all buying at the same price, you can bet they were all drinking at the same inn last night." "You don't have to convince me any more, Siuan." With a sigh, Egwene sat back, automatically catching the chair leg that always tried to fold when she did that. Clearly, something odd was happening, but what did it mean?

ən u kəɾ ɪnfluəns ðə tʃɔɪs ə sɪɾɝz ɪn ɛvɹi ədʒɑ? ɛvɹi ədʒɑ ɪksɛp ðə blu, ət list; ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən wʌn nu sɪɾɝ, bʌt mɔɹiə hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛl oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ən meɪbi ðə ɹɛd wɑz nɑɾ əfɛktəd; noʊ wʌn nu wʌt tʃeɪnʒəz ɪf ɛni hæd bɪn meɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɛd sɪɾɝz. ðə blæk maɪt bi bɪhaɪn ɪt, bʌt wʌt kəd ðeɪ ɡeɪn, ənlɛs ɔl ə ðoʊz tu-jʌŋ sɪɾɝz wɝ blæk? ðət simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪn ɛni keɪs; ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæd hæd ðət mʌtʃ ɪnfluəns, ðə hɔl wʊɾə bɪn ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz lɔŋ əɡoʊ. jɛɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə pæɾɝn ən koʊɪnsɪɾəns wəd nɑt hoʊld, ðən sʌmwʌn hæd tə bi ət ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə pɑsəbɪləɾiz, ði ɪmpɑsəbɪləɾiz, meɪd ðə dʌl peɪn bɪhaɪn əɹ aɪz ɡɹoʊ ə lɪɾəl ʃɑɹpɝ. "ɪf ðɪs tɝnz aʊt tə bi hæpənstæns æftɝ ɔl, sɪuən, jəɹ gɑnə ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɛvɝ θɪŋkɪŋ jə sɔ ə pʌzəl." ʃi fɔɹst ə smaɪl seɪɪŋ ðæt, tə teɪk aʊɾ ɛni stɪŋ. ən æmɪɝlɪn hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl wɪð əɹ wɝdz. "naʊ ðət juv kənvɪns mi ðəɹ ɪz ə pʌzəl, aɪ wɑn jə tə sɑlv ɪt.

And who could influence the choice of Sitters in every Ajah? Every Ajah except the Blue, at least; they had chosen one new Sitter, but Moria had been Aes Sedai well over a hundred years. And maybe the Red was not affected; no one knew what changes if any had been made in the Red Sitters. The Black might be behind it, but what could they gain, unless all of those too-young Sitters were Black? That seemed impossible in any case; if the Black Ajah had had that much influence, the Hall would have been all Darkfriends long ago. Yet if there was a pattern and coincidence would not hold, then someone had to be at the heart of it. Just thinking about the possibilities, the impossibilities, made the dull pain behind her eyes grow a little sharper. "If this turns out to be happenstance after all, Siuan, you're going to regret ever thinking you saw a puzzle." She forced a smile saying that, to take out any sting. An Amyrlin had to be careful with her words. "Now that you've convinced me there is a puzzle, I want you to solve it.

hu ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl, ən wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ æftɝ? əntɪl wi noʊ ðæt, wi doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ." "ɪz ðəɾ ɔl jə wɑnt?" sɪuən sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "bɪfɔɹ sʌpɝ, əɹ æftɝ?"

Who is responsible, and what are they after? Until we know that, we don't know anything." "Is that all you want?" Siuan said dryly. "Before supper, or after?"

"æftɝ wɪl əv tə du, aɪ səpoʊz," ɛɡwin snæpt, ðən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ət ði əbæʃt lʊk ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz feɪs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn teɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛdeɪk aʊɾ ɑn sɪuən. ən æmɪɝlɪnz wɝdz hæd paʊɝ, ən səmtaɪmz kɑnsəkwɛnsəz; ʃi hæd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. "æz sun əz jə kən wəd bi vɛɹi ɡʊd, ðoʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə maɪldɝ vɔɪs. "aɪ noʊ jəl bi əz kwɪk əz jə kæn." ʃəɡɹɪn əɹ nɑt, sɪuən sim tə ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ɛɡwinz aʊtbɝs keɪm fɹəm mɔɹ ðən əɹ oʊn sɑɹkæzəm. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ juθfəl əpɪɹəns, ʃi hæd jɪɹz ə pɹæktəs ət ɹiɾɪŋ feɪsəz.

"After will have to do, I suppose," Egwene snapped, then took a deep breath at the abashed look on the other woman's face. There was no point taking her headache out on Siuan. An Amyrlin's words had power, and sometimes consequences; she had to remember that. "As soon as you can would be very good, though," she said in a milder voice. "I know you'll be as quick as you can." Chagrined or not, Siuan seemed to understand that Egwene's outburst came from more than her own sarcasm. Despite her youthful appearance, she had years of practice at reading faces.

"ʃæl aɪ ɡoʊ faɪn hɑlimə?" ʃi sɛd, hæf ɹaɪzɪŋ. ðə læk ə tɑɹtnəs ətætʃt tə ðə wʊmənz neɪm wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə hɝ kənsɝn. "ɪt woʊn teɪk ə mɪnət."

"Shall I go find Halima?" she said, half rising. The lack of tartness attached to the woman's name was a measure of her concern. "It won't take a minute."

"ɪf aɪ ɡɪv weɪ fəɹ ɛvɹi eɪk, əl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ dʌn," ɛɡwin sɛd, oʊpənɪŋ ðə foʊldɝ.

"If I give way for every ache, I'll never get anything done," Egwene said, opening the folder.

"naʊ, wʌt juv fəɹ mi tədeɪ?" ʃi kɛpt əɹ hænz ɑn ðə peɪpɝz, ðoʊ, tə stɑp fɹəm ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ hɛd.

"Now, what do you have for me today?" She kept her hands on the papers, though, to stop from rubbing her head.

wʌn ə sɪuənz tæsks itʃ mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz tə fɛtʃ wʌt ði ədʒəz wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ nɛtwɝks ʌv aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz, əlɔŋ wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl sɪstɝz hæd pæst ɑn tə ðɛɹ ədʒəz ən ði ədʒəz hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pæs ɑn tə ɛɡwin. ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹɑsɛs ə sɪvɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪt stɪl ɡeɪv ə fɛɹ pɪktʃɝ ə ðə wɝld wən æɾəd tə wʌt sɪuən pʊɾ ɪn. ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə hoʊld ɑn tə ði eɪdʒəns ðət hæd bɪn hɝz əz æmɪɝlɪn baɪ ðə sɪmpəl ɪkspiɾiənt ə ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə tɛl ɛniwʌn u ðeɪ wɝ dɪspaɪɾ ɛvɹi ɛfɝt baɪ ðə hɔl, ən ɪn ði ɛnd, noʊ wʌn kəd ɡeɪnseɪ ðət ðoʊz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz wɝ ði æmɪɝlɪnz, ən ðət ðeɪ ʃəd baɪ ɹaɪts ɹipɔɹt tə ɛɡwin. oʊ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ɛn ʌv ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪt, ən stɪl wɑz ɑn əkeɪʒən, bʌt noʊ wʌn kəd dɪnaɪ ðə fæks. əz juʒəwəl, ðə fɝst ɹipɔɹt keɪm fɹəm niðɝ ði ədʒəz nɔɹ sɪuən, bʌt lin, ɹɪɾən ɑn θɪn ʃits ə peɪpɝ ɪn ə floʊɪŋ ɛləɡən hænd. ɛɡwin kəd nɑt si ɪɡzækli waɪ, bʌt jə kəd nɛvɝ daʊt ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ lin ɹoʊt hæd bɪn ɹɪɾən baɪ ə wʊmən. ðoʊz peɪdʒəz ɛɡwin hɛl tə ðə teɪbəl-læmps fleɪm wʌn baɪ wʌn əz sun əz ʃi ɹɛd ðɛm, lɛɾɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ bɝn ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ fɪŋɡɝz, ðən kɹʌmplɪŋ ði æʃ. ɪt wəd hɑɹdli də fəɹ əɹ ən lin tə bɪheɪv laɪk nɪɹ-stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɪn pʌblɪk ðən əlaʊ wʌn ə hɝ ɹɪpɔɹts tə fɔl ɪndə ðə ɹɔŋ hænz.

One of Siuan's tasks each morning was to fetch what the Ajahs were willing to share from their networks of eyes-and-ears, along with whatever individual sisters had passed on to their Ajahs and the Ajahs had decided to pass on to Egwene. It was a strange process of sieving, yet it still gave a fair picture of the world when added to what Siuan put in. She had managed to hold on to the agents that had been hers as Amyrlin by the simple expedient of refusing to tell anyone who they were despite every effort by the Hall, and in the end, no one could gainsay that those eyes-and-ears were the Amyrlin's, and that they should by rights report to Egwene. Oh, there had been no end of grumbling over it, and still was on occasion, but no one could deny the facts. As usual, the first report came from neither the Ajahs nor Siuan, but Leane, written on thin sheets of paper in a flowing elegant hand. Egwene could not see exactly why, but you could never doubt that anything Leane wrote had been written by a woman. Those pages Egwene held to the table-lamp's flame one by one as soon as she read them, letting the paper burn almost to her fingers, then crumpling the ash. It would hardly do for her and Leane to behave like near-strangers in public then allow one of her reports to fall into the wrong hands.

vɛɹi fju sɪstɝz wɝ əwɛɹ ðət lin hæɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪnsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪtsɛlf. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ði oʊnli sɪstɝ u dɪd. ɪt wɑz ə hjumən feɪlɪŋ tə wɑtʃ kinli wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ daʊn ðə stʃɹit waɪl ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt leɪ ɹaɪɾ ət jəɹ fit, ən ðə laɪt nu ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ əz mɛni hjumən feɪlɪŋz əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, lin hæd lɪɾəl nu tə kəmjunəkeɪt.

Very few sisters were aware that Leane had eyes-and-ears inside Tar Valon itself. She might have been the only sister who did. It was a human failing to watch keenly what was happening down the street while ignoring what lay right at your feet, and the Light knew Aes Sedai had as many human failings as anyone else. Unfortunately, Leane had little new to communicate.

hɝ pipəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi kəmpleɪn ə fɪlθi stʃɹits ðət wɝ ɪnkɹisɪŋli deɪnʒɝəs æftɝ dɑɹk ən lɪɾəl seɪfɝ baɪ deɪlaɪt. wʌns kɹaɪm hæd bɪn ɔl bʌɾ ənnoʊn ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, bʌt naʊ ðə taʊɝ ɡɑɹdz hæɾ əbændən ðə stʃɹits tə pətʃɹoʊl ðə hɑɹbɝz ən ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊɝz. ɪksɛp fəɹ kəlɛktɪŋ ðə kʌstəmz duɾiz ən baɪɪŋ səplaɪz, boʊθ dʌn θɹu ɪntɝmiɾiɛɹiz, ðə waɪt taʊɝ sim tə hæv ʃʌɾ ɪtsɛlf ɔf fɹəm ðə sɪɾi kəmplitli. ðə ɡɹeɪt dɔɹz ðəɾ əlaʊd ðə pʌblɪk tə ɛntɝ ðə taʊɝ ɹɪmeɪnd ʃʌɾ ən bɑɹd, ən noʊ wʌn hæd sin ə sɪstɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊɝ tə noʊ hɝ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪns ðə sidʒ bɪɡæn, ɪf nɑɾ ɝliɝ. ɔl kɑnfɝmeɪʃən ʌv wʌt lin hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd bɪfɔɹ. ðə læs peɪdʒ meɪɾ ɛɡwinz aɪbɹaʊz ɹaɪz, ðoʊ. ɹumɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹits sɛd ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd faʊn ə sikɹət weɪ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ən wəɾ əpɪɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz wɪð ɪz hoʊl ɑɹmi ɛni deɪ.

Her people in the city complained of filthy streets that were increasingly dangerous after dark and little safer by daylight. Once crime had been all but unknown in Tar Valon, but now the Tower Guards had abandoned the streets to patrol the harbors and the bridge towers. Except for collecting the customs duties and buying supplies, both done through intermediaries, the White Tower seemed to have shut itself off from the city completely. The great doors that allowed the public to enter the Tower remained shut and barred, and no one had seen a sister outside the Tower to know her as Aes Sedai since the siege began, if not earlier. All confirmation of what Leane had reported before. The last page made Egwene's eyebrows rise, though. Rumor in the streets said Gareth Bryne had found a secret way into the city and would appear inside the walls with his whole army any day.

"lin wʊɾə sɛɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn hæd bɹiðd ə wɝd ðət saʊndəd laɪk ðeɪ mɛnt ɡeɪtweɪz," sɪuən sɛd kwɪkli wən ʃi sɔ ɛɡwinz ɪkspɹɛʃən. ʃi hæd ɹɛɾ ɔl ə ðiz ɹɪpɔɹts ɔlɹɛɾi, ʌv kɔɹs, ən nu wʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz siɪŋ baɪ wɪtʃ peɪdʒ ʃi hɛld. ʃɪftɪŋ ɑn ði ənstɛɾi stul, sɪuən ɔlmoʊs fɛl ɔf ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts, ʃi wɑz peɪɪŋ soʊ lɪɾəl hid. ɪt dɪd nɑt sloʊ hɝ daʊn ə hɛɹ, ðoʊ. "æn jə kən bi ʃʊɹ ɡɛɹɪθ hæzən lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ slɪp," ʃi wɛn ɑn waɪl stɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf.

"Leane would have said if anyone had breathed a word that sounded like they meant gateways," Siuan said quickly when she saw Egwene's expression. She had read all of these reports already, of course, and knew what Egwene was seeing by which page she held. Shifting on the unsteady stool, Siuan almost fell off onto the carpets, she was paying so little heed. It did not slow her down a hair, though. "And you can be sure Gareth hasn't let anything slip," she went on while still righting herself.

"nɑt ðəɾ ɛni ʌv ɪz soʊlʒɝz ɑɹ ful ɪnʌf tə dɪzɝt tə ðə sɪɾi naʊ, bʌɾ i noʊz wən tə kip ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt. hi dʒʌst əz ðə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ ətækɪŋ wɛɹ i kæn pɑsəbli bi. hiz dʌn ði ɪmpɑsəbəl ɔfən ɪnʌf ðət pipəl ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə. ðæts ɔl." haɪɾɪŋ ə smaɪl, ɛɡwin hɛl ðə peɪpɝ mɛnʃənɪŋ lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ tə ðə fleɪm ən wɑtʃt ɪt kɝl ən blækən. ə fju mʌnθs pæst, sɪuən wʊɾə ɔfɝɾ ən æsəd kɑmɛn əbaʊt ðə mæn ɪnstɛɾ ə pɹeɪz. hi wʊɾə bɪn "ɡɛɹɪθ blʌɾi bɹaɪn," nɑt ɡɛɹɪθ. ʃi kəd nɑt pɑsəbli mɪs duɪŋ ɪz lɔnʒɹi ən pɑlɪʃɪŋ ɪz buts, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd sin əɹ stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɑn ðoʊz ɹɛɹ taɪmz wən i keɪm tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kæmp. stɛɹɪŋ, ən ðən ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ ɪf i soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət hɝ. sɪuən! ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ! sɪuən hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti jɪɹz, ən æmɪɝlɪn fəɹ tɛn, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊ mɔɹ aɪdiə haʊ tə dil wɪð biɪŋ ɪn lʌv ðən ə dʌk hæɾ əbaʊt ʃɪɹɪŋ ʃip.

"Not that any of his soldiers are fool enough to desert to the city now, but he knows when to keep his mouth shut. He just has the reputation for attacking where he can't possibly be. He's done the impossible often enough that people expect him to. That's all." Hiding a smile, Egwene held the paper mentioning Lord Gareth to the flame and watched it curl and blacken. A few months past, Siuan would have offered an acid comment about the man instead of praise. He would have been "Gareth bloody Bryne," not Gareth. She could not possibly miss doing his laundry and polishing his boots, but Egwene had seen her staring at him on those rare times when he came to the Aes Sedai camp. Staring, and then running away if he so much as glanced at her. Siuan! Running away! Siuan had been Aes Sedai for more than twenty years, and Amyrlin for ten, but she had no more idea how to deal with being in love than a duck had about shearing sheep.

ɛɡwin kɹʌmbəl ði æʃ ən dʌstɪɾ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ, hɝ smaɪl feɪɾɪŋ. ʃi hæd noʊ ɹum tə tɔk əbaʊt sɪuən. ʃi wɑz ɪn lʌv, tu, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən noʊ wɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld ɡɔɪn wɑz, əɹ wʌt tə də ɪf ʃi lɝnd. hi hæɾ ɪz duɾi tə ændɝ, ən ʃi hɝz tə ðə taʊɝ. ən ðə wʌn weɪ tə bɹɪdʒ ðət kæzəm, bɑndɪŋ hɪm, maɪt lɛd tə hɪz dɛθ. bɛɾɝ tə lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ, fɝɡɛɾ ɪm ɪntaɪɝli. əz izi əz fɝɡɛɾɪŋ əɹ oʊn neɪm. ən ʃi wəd bɑn hɪm. ʃi nu ðæt. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi kəd nɑt bɑn ðə mæn wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wɛɹ i wɑz, wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn hɪm, soʊ ɪɾ ɔl keɪm fʊl sɝkəl. mɛn wɝ . . . ə bɑðɝbækslæʃ pɔzɪŋ tə pɹɛs əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛnst əɹ tɛmpəlz - ɪt dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə lɛsən ðə pʌlsɪŋ peɪn - ʃi pʊt ɡɔɪn aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪnd. əz fɑɹ aʊɾ əz ʃi kʊd. ʃi θɔt ʃi hæɾ ə fɔɹteɪst ʌv wʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk hævɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ; ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ɡɔɪn ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. ən laɪəbəl tə kɪk ɪts weɪ ɪndə hɝ kɑnʃəsnəs ət ðə moʊst ɪnkənvinjən taɪm. kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bɪznəs ət hænd, ʃi pɪkt ʌp ðə nɛkst ʃit.

Egwene crumbled the ash and dusted her hands together, her smile fading. She had no room to talk about Siuan. She was in love, too, but she did not even know where in the world Gawyn was, or what to do if she learned. He had his duty to Andor, and she hers to the Tower. And the one way to bridge that chasm, bonding him, might lead to his death. Better to let him go, forget him entirely. As easy as forgetting her own name. And she would bond him. She knew that. Of course, she could not bond the man without knowing where he was, without having her hands on him, so it all came full circle. Men were . . . a bother\ Pausing to press her fingers against her temples - it did nothing to lessen the pulsing pain - she put Gawyn out of her mind. As far out as she could. She thought she had a foretaste of what it was like having a Warder; there was always something of Gawyn in the back of her head. And liable to kick its way into her consciousness at the most inconvenient time. Concentrating on the business at hand, she picked up the next sheet.

mʌtʃ ə ðə wɝl hæd vænɪʃt, əz fɑɹ əz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz wɝ kənsɝnd. lɪɾəl nuz keɪm fɹəm ðə lænz hɛl baɪ ðə sintʃæn, ən ðət dɪvaɪɾəd bɪtwin fænsɪfəl dɪskɹɪpʃənz ə sintʃæn bists dɪlɪvɝɾ əz pɹuf ðeɪ wɝ juzɪŋ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, hɔɹəfaɪɪŋ teɪlz ʌv wɪmən biɪŋ tɛstəd tə si wɛðɝ ðeɪ ʃəd bi kɑlɝɾ əz deɪmeɪn, ən dɪpɹɛsɪŋ stɔɹiz ʌv. . . æksɛptəns. ðə sintʃæn, ɪt simd, wɝ noʊ wɝs ɹulɝz ðən ɛni ʌðɝz ən bɛɾɝ ðən səm - əz lɔŋ əz jə wɝ nɑɾ ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl - ən ɔl tu mɛni pipəl əpɪɹd tə hæv ɡɪvən ʌp θɔts ə ɹɪzɪstəns wʌns ɪt bɪkeɪm klɪɹ ðə sintʃæn wəd lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ lɪvz. ɑɹæd dumən wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæd, pɹədusɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌt ɹumɝz, ədmɪɾəd əz sətʃ baɪ ðə sɪstɝz u ɹoʊt ðə ɹɪpɔɹts bʌɾ ɪnkluɾəd dʒʌs tə ʃoʊ ðə steɪt ðə kʌntʃɹi wɑz ɪn. kɪŋ ælsələm wɑz dɛd. noʊ, hi hæd bɪɡʌn tʃænəlɪŋ ən ɡɔn mæd.

Much of the world had vanished, as far as eyes-and-ears were concerned. Little news came from the lands held by the Seanchan, and that divided between fanciful descriptions of Seanchan beasts delivered as proof they were using Shadowspawn, horrifying tales of women being tested to see whether they should be collared as damane, and depressing stories of. . . acceptance. The Seanchan, it seemed, were no worse rulers than any others and better than some - as long as you were not a woman who could channel - and all too many people appeared to have given up thoughts of resistance once it became clear the Seanchan would let them go on with their lives. Arad Doman was almost as bad, producing nothing but rumors, admitted as such by the sisters who wrote the reports but included just to show the state the country was in. King Alsalam was dead. No, he had begun channeling and gone mad.

ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi, ðə ɡɹeɪt kæptən, ɔlsoʊ wɑz dɛd, əɹ i hæd jusɝp ðə θɹoʊn, əɹ wɑz ɪnveɪɾɪŋ sɑldɑiə.

Rodel Ituralde, the Great Captain, also was dead, or he had usurped the throne, or was invading Saldaea.

ðə kaʊnsəl ə mɝtʃəns wɝ ɔl dɛd, əz wɛl, əɹ hæd flɛd ðə kʌntʃɹi, əɹ bɪɡʌn ə sɪvəl wɔɹ oʊvɝ u ðə nɛks kɪŋ wɑz tə bi. ɛni ʌv ðoʊz maɪɾ əv bɪn tʃɹu. əɹ nʌn. ði ədʒəz wɝ əkʌstəm tə siɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌt naʊ ə θɝɾ ə ðə wɝl hæd bɪn ɛnvɛləpt ɪn dɛns fɑɡ, wɪð oʊnli ðə taɪniəst ɡæps. ət list, ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni klɪɹɝ vjuz, noʊ ədʒɑ hæd dn tə pæs ɑn wʌt ðeɪ sɔ ðɛɹ.

The Council of Merchants were all dead, as well, or had fled the country, or begun a civil war over who the next king was to be. Any of those might have been true. Or none. The Ajahs were accustomed to seeing everything, but now a third of the world had been enveloped in dense fog, with only the tiniest gaps. At least, if there were any clearer views, no Ajah had deigned to pass on what they saw there.

ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm wɑz ðət ði ədʒəz sɔ dɪfɹən θɪŋz əz hævɪŋ pɛɹəmaʊn ɪmpɔɹɾəns, ən lɑɹdʒli ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls.

Another problem was that the Ajahs saw different things as having paramount importance, and largely ignored anything else.

ðə ɡɹinz, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, wɝ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli kənsɝn oʊvɝ teɪlz ə bɔɹɾɝlənd ɑɹmiz nɪɹ nu bɹəm, hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz fɹəm ðə blaɪt ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi ɡɑɹɾɪŋ. ðɛɹ ɹipɔɹt tɔkt ə ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ən oʊnli ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ hæd tə bi dʌn ən dʌn naʊ. nɑt ðət ðeɪ sədʒɛstəɾ ɛniθɪŋ, əɹ soʊ mʌtʃ əz hɪntəd, jɛt fɹəstʃɹeɪʃənz keɪm θɹu ɪn ðə kɹæmpt, heɪsti hændʒɹaɪɾɪŋ ðət spaɪɾɝd ɝdʒənli əkɹɔs ðə peɪdʒ. ɛɡwin hæd ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðət sɪtʃueɪʃən fɹəm ɪleɪn, bʌt ʃi wɑz kɑntɛn tə lɛt ðə ɡɹinz næʃ ðɛɹ tiθ fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, sɪns sɪuən hæd ɹɪvild waɪ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf tə sɛt mæɾɝz stʃɹeɪt. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɝ eɪdʒən ɪn nu bɹəm, ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɝ əkʌmpənid baɪ fɪfti əɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd sɪstɝz, pɝhæps tu hʌnʒɹəd. ðə nʌmbɝ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt bi ənsɝɾən, ən ɪt mʌs bi waɪldli ɪnfleɪɾəd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns wɑz ə fæk ðə ɡɹinz hæd tə bi əwɛɹ ʌv, ðoʊ ðə ɹɪpɔɹts ðeɪ sɛn tə ɛɡwin nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ðɛm. noʊ ədʒɑ hæd mɛnʃən ðoʊz sɪstɝz ɪn ðɛɹ ɹɪpɔɹts. ɪn ði ɛnd, ðoʊ, ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl dɪfɝəns bɪtwin tu hʌnʒɹəd sɪstɝz ən tu. noʊ wʌn kəd bi sɝɾən u ðoʊz sɪstɝz wɝ əɹ waɪ ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ, jɛt poʊkɪŋ ə noʊz ɪn wəd ʃʊɹli bi sin əz ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ. ɪt sim stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ðeɪ kəd bi ɛnɡeɪdʒd ɪn ə wɔɹ bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən stɪl bi hɛl bæk fɹəm ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ baɪ kʌstəm, bʌt θæŋkfəli, ɪt wɑz soʊ.

The Greens, for example, were particularly concerned over tales of Borderland armies near New Braem, hundreds of leagues from the Blight they were supposed to be guarding. Their report talked of the Borderlanders and only the Borderlanders, as if something had to be done and done now. Not that they suggested anything, or so much as hinted, yet frustrations came through in the cramped, hasty handwriting that spidered urgently across the page. Egwene had the truth of that situation from Elayne, but she was content to let the Greens gnash their teeth for the moment, since Siuan had revealed why they were not rushing off to set matters straight. According to her agent in New Braem, the Borderlanders were accompanied by fifty or a hundred sisters, perhaps two hundred. The number of Aes Sedai might be uncertain, and it must be wildly inflated, of course, but their presence was a fact the Greens had to be aware of, though the reports they sent to Egwene never mentioned them. No Ajah had mentioned those sisters in their reports. In the end, though, there was little difference between two hundred sisters and two. No one could be certain who those sisters were or why they were there, yet poking a nose in would surely be seen as interfering. It seemed strange that they could be engaged in a war between Aes Sedai and still be held back from interfering with another sister by custom, but thankfully, it was so.

"æt lis ðeɪ doʊn sədʒɛst sɛndɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə keɪɛmlɪn." ɛɡwin blɪŋkt, ðə peɪn bɪhaɪn əɹ aɪz ʃɑɹpən baɪ fɑloʊɪŋ ðə taɪt lɛɾɝz.

"At least they don't suggest sending anyone to Caemlyn." Egwene blinked, the pain behind her eyes sharpened by following the tight letters.

sɪuən ɡeɪv ə dɝɪsɪv snɔɹt. "waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ? əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ noʊ, ɪleɪn ɪz lɛɾɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪl ən vændin ɡaɪd hɝ, soʊ ðəɹ ʃʊɹ ðəl ɡɛt ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ kwin, ən ə ɡɹin ət ðæt. bɪsaɪdz, əz lɔŋ ði æʃəmən steɪ aʊɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn, noʊ wʌn wɑns tə teɪk ðə tʃæns ə stɝɪŋ əm ʌp. ðə weɪ θɪŋz stænd, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl tʃɹaɪ pʊlɪŋ wɑsp-dʒɛliz aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ wɪð əɹ bɛɹ hænz, ən ivən ðə ɡɹinz noʊ ɪt. ɛniweɪ, ðət woʊn stɑp səm sɪstɝ, ɡɹin əɹ ʌðɝwaɪz, fɹəm dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn.

Siuan gave a derisive snort. "Why should they? As far as they know, Elayne is letting Merilille and Vandene guide her, so they're sure they'll get their Aes Sedai queen, and a Green at that. Besides, as long the Asha'man stay out of Caemlyn, no one wants to take the chance of stirring them up. The way things stand, we might as well try pulling wasp-jellies out of the water with our bare hands, and even the Greens know it. Anyway, that won't stop some sister, Green or otherwise, from dropping into Caemlyn.

dʒʌst ə kwaɪət vɪzət tə si wʌn ə hɝ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz. əɹ tə hæv ə dʒɹɛs meɪd, əɹ baɪ ə sæɾəl, əɹ ðə laɪt noʊz waɪ ɛls."

Just a quiet visit to see one of her eyes-and-ears. Or to have a dress made, or buy a saddle, or the Light knows why else."

"ivən ðə ɡɹinz?" ɛɡwin sɛd tɑɹtli. ɛvɹiwʌn θɔɾ ə bɹaʊnz biɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən waɪts ðæt, ivən wən ɪt wɑz dɪmɑnstʃɹəbli nɑt soʊ, jɛt səmtaɪmz ʃi bɹɪsəld ə lɪɾəl ət hɪɹɪŋ ɡɹinz lʌmp təɡɛðɝ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm wʊmən. meɪbi ʃi dɪd θɪŋk ə hɝsɛlf əz ə ɡɹin, əɹ əz hævɪŋ bɪn wʌn, wɪtʃ wɑz sɪli. ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz ʌv ɔl ədʒəz ən nʌn - ʃi ədʒʌstəd ðə stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ɹimaɪndɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə ðə fækt ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd baɪ ðoʊz sɛvən stʃɹaɪps - ən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. jɛt ʃi dɪd fil ə - nɑt fɑndnəs; ðət wɑz tu stʃɹɔŋ - ə sɛns ə seɪmnəs bɪtwin hɝsɛlf ən ɡɹin sɪstɝz. "haʊ mɛni sɪstɝz ɑɹ ʌnəkaʊntɪd fɔɹ, sɪuən? ivən ðə wikəs kən tʃɹævəl wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ wɑnt, lɪŋkt, ən aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, sɪuən fɹaʊn ɪn θɔt. "əbaʊt twɛnti, aɪ θɪŋk," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "meɪbi ə fju lɛs. ðə nʌmbɝ tʃeɪnʒəz deɪ tə deɪ. noʊ wʌn kips tʃɹæk, ɹɪli. noʊ sɪstɝ wəd stæn stɪl fəɹ ɪt." ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, kɛɹfəli bælənsɪŋ hɝsɛlf ðɪs taɪm wən ði ənivən lɛɡz meɪɾ əɹ stul lɝtʃ. "juv dʒʌɡəl mæɾɝz bjuɾəfli, soʊ fɑɹ, mʌðɝ, bʌɾ ɪt kæn læst. ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ðə hɔl wɪl faɪn aʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðæts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðeɪ maɪɾ æksɛp kipɪŋ ðə sintʃæn pɹɪznɝz sikɹət - ðət wɪl bi sin əz vændinz bɪznəs, əɹ mɛɝɪlɪlz - bʌt ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ si foʊk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðəl lɝn əbaʊt ðə bɑɹɡən wɪð əm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. ən ðə kɪn, ɪf nɑt jəɹ plænz fəɹ ðɛm." sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn, ðoʊ feɪnli. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən haʊ ʃi hɝsɛlf fɛlt əbaʊt ði aɪdiə ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪtaɪɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs haʊ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wəd teɪk tə ðə noʊʃən. "maɪ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz hævən pɪkt ʌp ə ɡlɪmɝ, jɛt, bʌt sʌmbɑɾiz wɪl, əz ʃʊɹ əz sɝɾən. jə kæn dɪleɪ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, əɹ wɪl faɪn aʊɝsɛlvz weɪɾɪŋ θɹu ə skul ə sɪlvɝpaɪk."

"Even the Greens?" Egwene said tartly. Everyone thought of Browns being this way and Whites that, even when it was demonstrably not so, yet sometimes she bristled a little at hearing Greens lumped together as if they were all the same woman. Maybe she did think of herself as a Green, or as having been one, which was silly. The Amyrlin was of all Ajahs and none - she adjusted the stole on her shoulders, reminding herself of the fact represented by those seven stripes - and she had never belonged to one in the first place. Yet she did feel a - not fondness; that was too strong - a sense of sameness between herself and Green sisters. "How many sisters are unaccounted for, Siuan? Even the weakest can Travel wherever they want, linked, and I wish I knew where they went." For a moment, Siuan frowned in thought. "About twenty, I think," she said finally. "Maybe a few less. The number changes day to day. No one keeps track, really. No sister would stand still for it." She leaned forward, carefully balancing herself this time when the uneven legs made her stool lurch. "You've juggled matters beautifully, so far, Mother, but it can't last. Eventually, the Hall will find out everything that's going on in Caemlyn. They might accept keeping the Seanchan prisoners secret - that will be seen as Vandene's business, or Merilille's - but they already know there are Sea Folk in Caemlyn, and they'll learn about the bargain with them sooner or later. And the Kin, if not your plans for them." Siuan snorted again, though faintly. She was not certain how she herself felt about the idea of Aes Sedai retiring into the Kin, much less how other sisters would take to the notion. "My eyes-and-ears haven't picked up a glimmer, yet, but somebody's will, as sure as certain. You can't delay much longer, or we'll find ourselves wading through a school of silverpike."

"wʌn ə ðiz deɪz," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd, "aɪl əv tə si ðiz sɪlvɝpaɪk jəɹ ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt." ʃi hɛld ʌp ə hæn əz ði ʌðɝ wʊmən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "wʌn deɪ. ði əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə si foʊk wɪl kɑz pɹɑbləmz," ʃi kənfɛst, "bʌt wən ði ədʒəz hɪɹ hɪns, ðeɪ woʊn ɹilaɪz ɹaɪɾ əweɪ wʌt ðəɹ hɪɹɪŋ. sɪstɝz titʃɪŋ si foʊk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn? ɪts ənhɝɾ ʌv, bʌɾ u ɪz gɑnə æsk kwɛstʃənz əɹ ɪntɝfɪɹ, əɡɛnst ɔl kʌstəm? aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɪl bi ɔl sɔɹts ʌv ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ, meɪbi səm kwɛstʃənz kɔld ɪn ðə hɔl, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɪt kʌmz aʊt ðət ðəɹ ɪz ə bɑɹɡən, əl əv ɪntʃɹədus maɪ plæn fəɹ ðə kɪn."

"One of these days," Egwene muttered, "I'll have to see these silverpike you're always talking about." She held up a hand as the other woman opened her mouth. "One day. The agreement with the Sea Folk will cause problems," she confessed, "but when the Ajahs hear hints, they won't realize right away what they're hearing. Sisters teaching Sea Folk in Caemlyn? It's unheard of, but who is going to ask questions or interfere, against all custom? I'm sure there will be all sorts of grumbling, maybe some questions called in the Hall, but before it comes out that there is a bargain, I will have introduced my plan for the Kin."

"ju θɪŋk ðət woʊnt ʃɑɹpən ðɛɹ tiθ?" ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl, sɪuən bɛɹli bɑðɝd tə haɪɾ əɹ ɪnkɹədulɪɾi. ɪn fækt, ʃi skaʊld wɪð ɪt.

"You think that won't sharpen their teeth?" Shifting her shawl, Siuan barely bothered to hide her incredulity. In fact, she scowled with it.

"ɪt wɪl kɑz ɑɹɡjəmənt," ɛɡwin əlaʊd dʒudɪʃɪsli. ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl ʌndɝsteɪtmənt. ɪt wəd kɑz ən ʌpɹɔɹ wɑz wʌɾ ɪt wəd du, wʌns ðə hoʊl wɑz noʊn. laɪkli əz kloʊs tə ə ɹaɪəɾ əz hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn sin əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðə taʊɝ hæd bɪn dwɪndəlɪŋ fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz naʊ, ɪf nɑt mɔɹ, ən ʃi plæn tə pʊɾ ən ɛn tə ðæt. "bʌɾ aɪ də ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ sloʊli. ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bi ɹɪlʌktən tə tɔk əbaʊɾ eɪdʒ, sɪuən, bʌt ðəl fɪɡjɝ aʊt sun ɪnʌf ðət swɛɹɪŋ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd ʃɔɹɾənz əɹ laɪvz baɪ hæf ət list. noʊ wʌn wɑns tə daɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ mʌst." "ɪf ðəɹ kənvɪns ðəɹ ɹɪli ɪz ə kɪnswʊmən huz sɪks hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊld," sɪuən sɛɾ ɪn ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ toʊnz, ən ɛɡwin saɪd wɪð vɛkseɪʃən. ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz ənsɝɾən əbaʊt, ðə kɪnz kleɪmz ə lɔndʒɛvəɾi. ʃi væljud sɪuənz ædvaɪs, væljud ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt dʒʌst seɪ wʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə hɪɹ, bʌɾ ət taɪmz ðə wʊmən sim tə dʒɹæɡ hɝ hilz əz hɑɹɾ əz ɹoʊmændə əɹ ləleɪn.

"It will cause argument," Egwene allowed judiciously. A considerable understatement. It would cause an uproar was what it would do, once the whole was known. Likely as close to a riot as had ever been seen among Aes Sedai. But the Tower had been dwindling for a thousand years now, if not more, and she planned to put an end to that. "But I do intend to go slowly. Aes Sedai may be reluctant to talk about age, Siuan, but they'll figure out soon enough that swearing on the Oath Rod shortens our lives by half at least. No one wants to die before they must." "If they're convinced there really is a Kinswoman who's six hundred years old," Siuan said in grudging tones, and Egwene sighed with vexation. That was another thing the other woman was uncertain about, the Kin's claims of longevity. She valued Siuan's advice, valued that she did not just say what Egwene wanted to hear, but at times the woman seemed to drag her heels as hard as Romanda or Lelaine.

"ɪf nid bi, sɪuən," ʃi sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli, "aɪl dʒʌs lɛt ðə sɪstɝz tɔk tə ə fju wɪmən ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɹ mɔɹ oʊldɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ðeɪ meɪ tʃɹaɪ tə dɪsmɪs əm əz waɪldɝz ən laɪɝz, bʌt ɹin kɔɹli kən pɹuv ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ən wɛn. soʊ kən ʌðɝz. wɪð lʌk, əl kənvɪns ðə sɪstɝz tə æksɛp biɪŋ fɹiɾ ə ðə θɹi oʊðz soʊ ðeɪ kən ɹɪtaɪɹ ɪndə ðə kɪn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɛvɝ lɝn ðɛɹz ə bɑɹɡən wɪð ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ən wʌns ðeɪ æksɛpt ɛni sɪstɝ biɪŋ fɹiɾ ə ði oʊðz, ɪt woʊn bi nɪɹli əz hɑɹd tə kənvɪns əm tə lɛt ðə si foʊk sɪstɝz ɡoʊ. bɪsaɪd ðæt, ðə ɹɛst ə ðəɾ əɡɹimən ɪz smɔl tɝnəps. əz jə kip seɪɪŋ, skɪl ən ə dɛf hæn ɑɹ nɛsəsɛɹi tə ɡɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ dʌn ɪn ðə hɔl, bʌt lʌk ɪz æbsəlutli ɹikwaɪɝd. wɛl, əl bi əz skɪlfəl ən dɛft əz aɪ kən bi, ən əz fəɹ lʌk, ði ɑdz sim tə bi ɪn maɪ feɪvɝ fəɹ wʌns." sɪuən ɡɹɪməst ən hɛmd ən hɔd, bʌt ʃi hæd tə əɡɹi ɪn ði ɛnd. ʃi ivən əɡɹid ðəɾ ɛɡwin maɪt pʊl ɪɾ ɔf, wɪð lʌk, ən taɪmɪŋ. nɑt ðət ʃi wɑz kənvɪnst əbaʊt ðə kɪn əɹ ði əɡɹimənt wɪð ði æθɑn maɪɹ iðɝ wʌn, bʌt wʌɾ ɛɡwin pɹəpoʊzd wɑz soʊ ənpɹɛsɪdɛntɪd ðəɾ ɪt sim ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt maɪt pæs ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌt wɑz fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðɛm. ɛɡwin wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə sɛɾəl fəɹ ðæt. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz leɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl, ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ɪnʌf sɪɾɝz stʊɾ ɪn ɑpəzɪʃən tə meɪk faɪndɪŋ ə kənsɛnsəs hɑɹd wɝk ət bɛst, ən nʌθɪŋ wɑz dʌn ɪn ðə hɔl wɪθaʊɾ ət lis ðə lɛsɝ kənsɛnsəs ən juʒəwəli nɑt wɪθaʊt ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ. ɪt sim tə hɝ ðət moʊs dilɪŋz wɪð ðə hɔl kənsɪstəɾ ə kənvɪnsɪŋ əm tə də wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn tə. ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ðɪs tə bi ɛni dɪfɹənt. waɪl ðə ɡɹinz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz, ðə ɡɹeɪz foʊkəst saʊθ ət pɹizɛnt. ɛvɹi ədʒɑ wɑz fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ ðə ɹɪpɔɹts fɹəm ɪljən ən tiɹ ə lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ʌv waɪldɝz əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk, wɪtʃ ðeɪ faʊn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, ɪf tʃɹu, ðoʊ ðəɹ sim stʃɹɔŋ daʊt ðəɾ ɪt kəd bi tʃɹu, əɹ ɛls sɪstɝz wʊɾə noʊn əbaʊɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. æftɝ ɔl, haʊ kəd sətʃ ə θɪŋ bi hɪɾən? noʊ wʌn mɛnʃən ðət ðeɪ hæd dʒʌst æksɛptɪd wʌt ðeɪ sɔ ɑn ðə sɝfəs ən nɛvɝ lʊk dipɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪz, ðoʊ, wɝ fæsəneɪɾəd baɪ ðə kəntɪnjud sintʃæn θɹɛt tə ɪljən ən ðə ɹisənli bɪɡʌn sidʒ ə ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. wɔɹz ən θɹɛts ʌv wɔɹ ɔlweɪz mɛzmɝaɪzd ɡɹeɪz, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ɛndɪŋ stʃɹaɪf. ən tə ɪkstɛndɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪnfluəns, ʌv kɔɹs; ɛvɹi taɪm ðə ɡɹeɪz stɑpt ə wɔɹ wɪð ə tʃɹiɾi, ðeɪ ɪnkɹis ði ɪnfluəns ʌv ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ʌv ɡɹeɪz moʊst ʌv ɔl. ðə sintʃæn sim bɪɑnd nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən, haʊɛvɝ, ət lis baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðə ɡɹeɪz' aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ sɛns ə biɪŋ θwɔɹɾəd keɪm θɹu ɪn kɝt wɝdz əbaʊt sintʃæn ɪnkɝʒənz əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɪnkɹisɪŋ fɔɹsɪz biɪŋ ɡæðɝd baɪ lɔɹd ɡɹɛɡɹɪn, ðə stuɝɾ ɪn ɪljən fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ə taɪɾəl ðət wɑz ə mæɾɝ ə səm kənsɝn ɪn ɪtsɛlf. tiɹ hæɾ ɪts oʊn stuɝd fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə, ən i wɑz bɪsidʒd ɪn ðə stoʊn baɪ noʊbəlz u ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɹænd. ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ sidʒ. ðə stoʊn hæɾ ɪts oʊn dɑks ən dɑɹlɪnz ɛnəmiz kəd nɑt kʌɾ ɔf səplaɪz ivən hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɪɾi əz ðeɪ dɪd, ən ðeɪ sim kɑntɛn tə sɪɾ ən weɪɾ ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. əɹ pɝhæps ðeɪ dʒʌs kəd nɑt si wʌt tə də nɛkst. oʊnli ði il hæɾ ɛvɝ teɪkən ðə stoʊn baɪ əsɔlt, ən noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ stɑɹvd ɪɾ aʊt. ðə ɡɹeɪz hæd səm hoʊps ɪn tiɹ.

"If need be, Siuan," she said irritably, "I'll just let the sisters talk to a few women a hundred years or more older than any of them. They may try to dismiss them as wilders and liars, but Reanne Corly can prove she was in the Tower, and when. So can others. With luck, I'll convince the sisters to accept being freed of the Three Oaths so they can retire into the Kin before they ever learn there's a bargain with the Atha'an Miere. And once they accept any sister being freed of the Oaths, it won't be nearly as hard to convince them to let the Sea Folk sisters go. Beside that, the rest of that agreement is small turnips. As you keep saying, skill and a deft hand are necessary to get anything done in the Hall, but luck is absolutely required. Well, I'll be as skillful and deft as I can be, and as for luck, the odds seem to be in my favor for once." Siuan grimaced and hemmed and hawed, but she had to agree in the end. She even agreed that Egwene might pull it off, with luck, and timing. Not that she was convinced about the Kin or the agreement with the Atha'an Miere either one, but what Egwene proposed was so unprecedented that it seemed the greater part of it might pass the Hall before they realized what was falling on them. Egwene was willing to settle for that. Whatever was laid before the Hall, almost always enough Sitters stood in opposition to make finding a consensus hard work at best, and nothing was done in the Hall without at least the lesser consensus and usually not without the greater. It seemed to her that most dealings with the Hall consisted of convincing them to do what they did not want to. There was certainly no reason for this to be any different. While the Greens concentrated on the Borderlanders, the Grays focused south at present. Every Ajah was fascinated by the reports from Illian and Tear of large numbers of wilders among the Sea Folk, which they found interesting, if true, though there seemed strong doubt that it could be true, or else sisters would have known about it before this. After all, how could such a thing be hidden? No one mentioned that they had just accepted what they saw on the surface and never looked deeper. The Grays, though, were fascinated by the continued Seanchan threat to Illian and the recently begun siege of the Stone of Tear. Wars and threats of war always mesmerized Grays, since they were dedicated to ending strife. And to extending their influence, of course; every time the Grays stopped a war with a treaty, they increased the influence of all Aes Sedai, but of Grays most of all. The Seanchan seemed beyond negotiation, however, at least by Aes Sedai, and the Grays' outraged sense of being thwarted came through in curt words about Seanchan incursions across the border and the increasing forces being gathered by Lord Gregorin, the Steward in Illian for the Dragon Reborn, a title that was a matter of some concern in itself. Tear had its own Steward for the Dragon Reborn, the High Lord Darlin Sisnera, and he was besieged in the Stone by nobles who refused to accept Rand. It was a very strange siege. The Stone had its own docks and Darlin's enemies could not cut off supplies even holding the rest of the city as they did, and they seemed content to sit and wait in any event. Or perhaps they just could not see what to do next. Only the Aiel had ever taken the Stone by assault, and no one had ever starved it out. The Grays had some hopes in Tear.

ɛɡwinz hɛd keɪm ʌp əz ʃi ɹɛd tə ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə peɪdʒ, ən ʃi hɝidli sɛt ðət peɪdʒ daʊn ən pɪkt ʌp ðə nɛkst. ðə ɡɹeɪz hæd hæd səm hoʊps. əpɛɹənli, ə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ hæd bɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə stoʊn, ən fɑloʊd tə ə miɾɪŋ wɪð haɪ lɔɹd tidoʊzɪn ən haɪ leɪɾi ɪstændə, tu ʌv ðə moʊs pɹɑmənən əmʌŋ ðə bɪsiɡɝz. "mɛɹænə," ʃi bɹiðd. "ðeɪ seɪ ɪt wɑz mɛɹænə æmbɹi, sɪuən." ʌnkɑnʃəsli, ʃi məsɑʒd əɹ tɛmpəl. ðə peɪn bɪhaɪn əɹ aɪz hæd ɹætʃəɾɪd ə lɪɾəl haɪɝ. "ʃi meɪ də səm ɡʊd." ɹaɪzɪŋ, sɪuən kɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts tə ə smɔl teɪbəl əɡɛns ðə tɛnt wɔl, wɛɹ sɛvɹəl mɪsmætʃt kʌps ən tu pɪtʃɝz sæɾ ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ. ðə sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ hɛl spaɪst waɪn, ðə blu-ɡleɪz pɑɾɝi ti, boʊθ sɛt ðəɹ ət fɝs laɪɾ əɡɛns ði æmɪɝlɪnz ɝaɪvəl ən boʊθ lɔŋ sɪns ɡɔn koʊld. noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛɡwin tə ɡoʊ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɔf tə ðə ɹɪvɝ. "æz lɔŋ əz tidoʊzɪn ən ði ʌðɝz doʊn ɹilaɪz u ʃiz ɹɪli wɝkɪŋ fɔɹ." sɪuənz ʃɔl slɪpt ɔf wʌn ʃoʊldɝ əz ʃi fɛl ðə saɪɾ ə ðə pɑɾɝi pɪtʃɝ, ən ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəɾ əɹ bɹifli əz ʃi tʃænəl faɪɝ, wɔɹmɪŋ ðə kɑntɛns. "ðeɪ woʊn tʃɹʌst əɹ tə nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ɪn ɡʊd feɪθ ɪf ðeɪ faɪn aʊt ʃiz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹnz kɹitʃɝ." fɪlɪŋ ə pɑlɪʃt pjuɾɝ kʌp wɪð ti, ʃi æɾəd dʒɛnɝəs dɑləps fɹəm ðə hʌni dʒɑɹ, stɝɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn wɛl, ən bɹɔt ðə kʌp bæk tə ɛɡwin. "ðɪs maɪt hɛlp jəɹ hɛd.

Egwene's head came up as she read to the bottom of the page, and she hurriedly set that page down and picked up the next. The Grays had had some hopes. Apparently, a Gray sister had been recognized coming out of the Stone, and followed to a meeting with High Lord Tedosian and High Lady Estanda, two of the most prominent among the besiegers. "Merana," she breathed. "They say it was Merana Ambrey, Siuan." Unconsciously, she massaged her temple. The pain behind her eyes had ratcheted a little higher. "She may do some good." Rising, Siuan crossed the carpets to a small table against the tent wall, where several mismatched cups and two pitchers sat on a tray. The silver pitcher held spiced wine, the blue-glazed pottery tea, both set there at first light against the Amyrlin's arrival and both long since gone cold. No one had expected Egwene to go riding off to the river. "As long as Tedosian and the others don't realize who she's really working for." Siuan's shawl slipped off one shoulder as she felt the side of the pottery pitcher, and the light of saidar surrounded her briefly as she channeled Fire, warming the contents. "They won't trust her to negotiate in good faith if they find out she's the Dragon Reborn's creature." Filling a polished pewter cup with tea, she added generous dollops from the honey jar, stirring it in well, and brought the cup back to Egwene. "This might help your head.

ɪts səm sɔɹɾ ə ɝb kənkɑkʃən tʃɛsə faʊnd, bʌt hʌni kʌts ðə teɪst." ɛɡwin tʊk ə kɔʃəs sɪp, ən sɛt ðə kʌp daʊn wɪð ə ʃʌɾɝ. ɪf ɪt teɪstəd ðət ʃɑɹp wɪð hʌni, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɪmædʒən ɪt wɪθaʊt. ðə hɛdeɪk maɪt bi bɛɾɝ. "haʊ kən jə teɪk ðɪs soʊ kɑmli, sɪuən? mɛɹænə tɝnɪŋ ʌp ɪn tiɹ ɪz ðə fɝst ɹil pɹuf wiv hæd. əl teɪk jəɹ sɪɾɝz əz koʊɪnsɪɾəns bɪfɔɹ ðæt." ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ðəɹ hæɾ oʊnli bɪn wɪspɝz, fɹəm ði ədʒəz əɹ fɹəm sɪuənz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz. ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən ðeɪ sim tə muv fɹili ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn pæləs waɪl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ðɛɹ. ðən ðə wɪspɝz ɡɹu hɔɹs ən ənizi, hɛzɪɾənt. ði aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn kɛɹhin dɪd nɑt wɑnə seɪ ɪt. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə ɹɪpit wʌt ðɛɹ eɪdʒəns sɛd. ðəɹ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən ðeɪ sim tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ ði ɔɹɾɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. wɝs wɝ ðə neɪmz ðət tʃɹɪkəld aʊt. səm wɝ wɪmən u hæd bɪn ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, əmʌŋ ðə fɝs tə ɹɪzɪst ɪleɪɾə, waɪl ʌðɝz wɝ wɪmən noʊn tə bi lɔɪəl tə ɪleɪɾə. noʊ wʌn hæd mɛnʃən kəmpʌlʃən əlaʊd ðəɾ ɛɡwin nu ʌv, bʌt ðeɪ hæd tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ ɪt.

It's some sort of herb concoction Chesa found, but honey cuts the taste." Egwene took a cautious sip, and set the cup down with a shudder. If it tasted that sharp with honey, she did not want to imagine it without. The headache might be better. "How can you take this so calmly, Siuan? Merana turning up in Tear is the first real proof we've had. I'll take your Sitters as coincidence before that." In the beginning, there had only been whispers, from the Ajahs or from Siuan's eyes-and-ears. There were Aes Sedai in Cairhien, and they seemed to move freely in and out of the Sun Palace while the Dragon Reborn was there. Then the whispers grew hoarse and uneasy, hesitant. The eyes-and-ears in Cairhien did not want to say it. No one wanted to repeat what their agents said. There were Aes Sedai in Cairhien, and they seemed to be following the orders of the Dragon Reborn. Worse were the names that trickled out. Some were women who had been in Salidar, among the first to resist Elaida, while others were women known to be loyal to Elaida. No one had mentioned Compulsion aloud that Egwene knew of, but they had to be thinking it.

"noʊ jus pʊlɪŋ jəɹ hɛɹ wən ðə wɪn ɪzən bloʊɪŋ ðə weɪ jə wɑnt," sɪuən ɹɪplaɪd, teɪkɪŋ əɹ stul əɡɛn. ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə kɹɔs əɹ niz, bʌt heɪstəli pʊt boʊθ fit bæk ɑn ðə kɑɹpət wən əɹ stul tɪltəd. mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl wɪð ə twɪtʃ ə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. ən wɑz fɔɹs tə bæləns əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ lɝtʃ. "ju hæv tə tʃɹɪm jəɹ seɪlz tə teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ə haʊ ðə wɪn ɪz bloʊɪŋ. θɪŋk kuli, ən jə meɪk ɪt bæk tə ʃɔɹ. ɡɛt jəɹ nɛk hɑt, ən jəl dʒɹaʊn." səmtaɪmz, sɪuən kəd saʊn əz ɪf ʃi stɪl wɝkt ə fɪʃɪŋ boʊt. "aɪ bɪliv jə nid mɔɹ ðən wʌn sɪp fəɹ ðət tə də ɛni ɡʊd, mʌðɝ."

"No use pulling your hair when the wind isn't blowing the way you want," Siuan replied, taking her stool again. She started to cross her knees, but hastily put both feet back on the carpet when her stool tilted. Muttering under her breath, she adjusted her shawl with a twitch of her shoulders. And was forced to balance against another lurch. "You have to trim your sails to take advantage of how the wind is blowing. Think coolly, and you make it back to shore. Get your neck hot, and you'll drown." Sometimes, Siuan could sound as if she still worked a fishing boat. "I believe you need more than one sip for that to do any good, Mother."

wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, ɛɡwin pʊʃt ðə kʌp ə lɪɾəl fɑɹðɝ fɹəm hɝ. ðə teɪs klɪŋɪŋ tə hɝ tʌŋ wɑz ət list əz bæɾ əz əɹ hɛdeɪk. "sɪuən, ɪf jə si ə weɪ tə meɪk jus ə ðɪs, aɪ wɪʃ jud tɛl mi. aɪ doʊn ivən wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt juzɪŋ ðə fæk ðət ɹænd meɪ hæv kəmpɛl sɪstɝz. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðəɾ i kəd hæv." niðɝ əbaʊt ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðəɾ i nu sətʃ ə ɹipʌlsɪv wiv, əɹ ðəɾ i kəd leɪ ðət wiv ɑn ɛniwʌn. ʃi nu ɪt - ənʌðɝ lɪɾəl ɡɪft fɹəm mɑɡiɾin - ən ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɪʃt ʃi kəd fɝɡɛt haʊ tə meɪk ɪt. "ɪn ðɪs keɪs, ɪɾ ɪzən soʊ mʌtʃ ə mæɾɝ ə juzɪŋ əz fɪɡjɝɪŋ aʊt ði ɪfɛks. hɪl əv tə bi dɛlt wɪð ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən meɪbi tɔɾ ə lɛsən, bʌt jə doʊnt wɑn sɪstɝz flaɪɪŋ ɔf æftɝ ɪm naʊ, ən ðiz teɪlz aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin meɪk ɛvɹiwʌn kɔʃəs." sɪuənz vɔɪs wɑz kɑm ɪnʌf, bʌt ʃi fɪdʒəɾɪd, klɪɹli ædʒəteɪɾəd ɪnwɝdli. ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd spik ə tu kɑmli. "æt ðə seɪm taɪm, wʌns ɛvɹiwʌn θɪŋks ɪt θɹu, ðəl ɹilaɪz ðɪs meɪks nɑnsɛns aʊɾ ə ðoʊz stɔɹiz əbaʊɾ ɪm səbmɪɾɪŋ tə ɪleɪɾə. ʃi maɪɾ əv sɛn sɪstɝz tə wɑtʃ oʊvɝ hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdn æksɛp sɪstɝz u wɑnə pʊl ɪleɪɾə daʊn. ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət wɪl pʊɾ ə lɪɾəl bækboʊn ɪn ðoʊz huv stɑɹɾəd θɪŋkɪŋ meɪbi ɪleɪɾə hæz ɪm ɑn ə lɛd. ðæts wʌn lɛs ɹizən fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə kənsɪɾɝ jildɪŋ tə hɝ."

With a grimace, Egwene pushed the cup a little farther from her. The taste clinging to her tongue was at least as bad as her headache. "Siuan, if you see a way to make use of this, I wish you'd tell me. I don't even want to think about using the fact that Rand may have Compelled sisters. I don't want to think about the possibility that he could have." Neither about the possibility that he knew such a repulsive weave, or that he could lay that weave on anyone. She knew it - another little gift from Moghedien - and she very much wished she could forget how to make it. "In this case, it isn't so much a matter of using as figuring out the effects. He'll have to be dealt with eventually, and maybe taught a lesson, but you don't want sisters flying off after him now, and these tales out of Cairhien make everyone cautious." Siuan's voice was calm enough, but she fidgeted, clearly agitated inwardly. It was nothing any Aes Sedai could speak of too calmly. "At the same time, once everyone thinks it through, they'll realize this makes nonsense out of those stories about him submitting to Elaida. She might have sent sisters to watch over him, but they wouldn't accept sisters who want to pull Elaida down. Realizing that will put a little backbone in those who've started thinking maybe Elaida has him on a lead. That's one less reason for anyone to consider yielding to her."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt kædzueɪn?" ɛɡwin sɛd. ʌv ɔl ðə neɪmz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin, ðət wʌn hæd sɛn ðə moʊst ʃɑk θɹu ðə sɪstɝz. kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn wɑz ə lɛdʒənd, ən ðəɹ wɝ əz mɛni dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ vɝʒənz ə ðə lɛdʒən əz əpɹuvɪŋ. səm sɪstɝz hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪt mʌs bi ə mɪsteɪk; kædzueɪn mʌs bi dɛd baɪ naʊ.

"What about Cadsuane?" Egwene said. Of all the names coming out of Cairhien, that one had sent the most shock through the sisters. Cadsuane Melaidhrin was a legend, and there were as many disapproving versions of the legend as approving. Some sisters had been sure it must be a mistake; Cadsuane must be dead by now.

ʌðɝz dʒʌst əpɪɹd tə wɪʃ ʃi wɝ dɛd. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən ʃi ɹɪmeɪn ɪn kɛɹhin æftɝ ɹænd dɪsəpɪɹd?" "aɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ maɪ pipəl kɛpt ən aɪ ɑn əɹ əz sun əz aɪ hɝɾ əɹ neɪm," sɪuən sɛd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ saʊndɪŋ əɾ ɔl kɑm. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ʃiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, aɪ dʒʌst səspɛkt, bʌɾ aɪ kən ɡɛɹənti ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs ə wik æftɝ i vænɪʃt." skwizɪŋ əɹ aɪz ʃʌt, ɛɡwin pɹɛs ðə hilz ə hɝ pɑmz əɡɛnst əɹ lɪdz. ðət hɑɹdli sim tə əfɛk ðə pʌlsɪŋ niɾəl ɪn əɹ hɛd. meɪbi ɹænd wɑz ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð ə blæk sɪstɝ, əɹ hæd bɪn. meɪbi hi hæd juz kəmpʌlʃən ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Others just appeared to wish she were dead. "Are you certain she remained in Cairhien after Rand disappeared?" "I made sure my people kept an eye on her as soon as I heard her name," Siuan said, no longer sounding at all calm. "I don't know she's a Darkfriend, I just suspect, but I can guarantee that she was in the Sun Palace a week after he vanished." Squeezing her eyes shut, Egwene pressed the heels of her palms against her lids. That hardly seemed to affect the pulsing needle in her head. Maybe Rand was in company with a Black sister, or had been. Maybe he had used Compulsion on Aes Sedai.

bæɾ ɪnʌf ɑn ɛniwʌn, bʌt sʌmhaʊ wɝs juzd ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɔɹ ɑmənəs. wʌt wɑz dɛɹɾ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz tɛn taɪmz, ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz, əz laɪkli tə bi juzd əɡɛns ðoʊz u kəd nɑt dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə dil wɪð hɪm, sʌmhaʊ. ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð ɹænd, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ðət tə ɪnfluəns hɝ. hi wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, naʊ, ðə hoʊp ə ðə wɝld ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm meɪbi ðə sɪŋɡəl ɡɹeɪɾəst θɹɛt ðə wɝl feɪst. meɪbi? ðə sintʃæn kəd nɑt də əz mʌtʃ dæmədʒ əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ən ʃi wɑz gɑnə juz ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðəɾ i hæd kəmpɛl sɪstɝz. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɹɪli wɑz ə dɪfɹənt wʊmən fɹəm ðəɾ ɪnkipɝz dɔɾɝ.

Bad enough on anyone, but somehow worse used on Aes Sedai, more ominous. What was dared against Aes Sedai was ten times, a hundred times, as likely to be used against those who could not defend themselves. Eventually they would have to deal with him, somehow. She had grown up with Rand, yet she could not allow that to influence her. He was the Dragon Reborn, now, the hope of the world and at the same time maybe the single greatest threat the world faced. Maybe? The Seanchan could not do as much damage as the Dragon Reborn. And she was going to use the possibility that he had Compelled sisters. The Amyrlin Seat really was a different woman from that innkeeper's daughter.

skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə pjuɾɝ kʌp ə soʊ-kɔl ti, ʃi pɪkt ɪɾ ʌp ən meɪd hɝsɛlf dʒɹɪŋk ðə vaɪl stʌf daʊn, ɡæɡɪŋ ən spləɾɝɪŋ ðə hoʊl weɪ. pɝhæps ðə teɪst wəd teɪk əɹ maɪn ɔf əɹ hɛdeɪk, ət list.

Scowling at the pewter cup of so-called tea, she picked it up and made herself drink the vile stuff down, gagging and spluttering the whole way. Perhaps the taste would take her mind off her headache, at least.

əz ʃi sɛt ðə kʌp daʊn wɪð ə ʃɑɹp klɪŋk ə mɛɾəl ɑn wʊd, æneɪjə pʊʃt ɪndə ðə tɛnt, maʊθ tɝn daʊn ən ə fɹaʊn kɹisɪŋ əɹ pleɪn feɪs.

As she set the cup down with a sharp clink of metal on wood, Anaiya pushed into the tent, mouth turned down and a frown creasing her plain face.

"ækæɹən ən ði ʌðɝz əv ɹɪtɝnd, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd. "mɔɹiə toʊl mi tə ɪnfɔɹm jə ʃiz kɔl ðə hɔl tə hɪɹ ðɛɹ ɹipɔɹt."

"Akarrin and the others have returned, Mother," she said. "Moria told me to inform you she has called the Hall to hear their report."

"soʊ hæv ɛskɹɑldi ən mɑlɪnd," mɔɹvɹɪn ənaʊnst, kʌmɪŋ ɪn bɪhaɪn æneɪjə wɪð maɪɹɛl.

"So have Escaralde and Malind," Morvrin announced, coming in behind Anaiya with Myrelle.

ðə ɡɹin simd ən ɪmədʒ ə sɝin fjʊɹi, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl, hɝ ɑləv feɪs smuð ən əɹ aɪz laɪk dɑɹk ɛmbɝz, bʌt mɔɹvɹɪn wɔɹ ə skaʊl tə meɪk æneɪjə lʊk plizd. "ðeɪɹ sɛndɪŋ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪd ɹʌnɪŋ tə faɪn ɔl ðə sɪɾɝz," ðə bɹaʊn sɛd. "wi kæn kætʃ ə wɪspɝ ʌv wʌɾ ækæɹən faʊnd, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ɛskɹɑldi ən ði ʌðɝz ɪntɛn tə juz ɪt tə pɹɑd ðə hɔl təwɔɹd sʌmθɪŋ." piɹɪŋ ət ðə dɑɹk dʒɹɛɡz floʊɾɪŋ ɪn ə fju dʒɹɑps ɪn ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə pjuɾɝ kʌp, ɛɡwin saɪd.

The Green seemed an image of serene fury, if that was possible, her olive face smooth and her eyes like dark embers, but Morvrin wore a scowl to make Anaiya look pleased. "They're sending novices and Accepted running to find all the Sitters," the Brown said. "We can't catch a whisper of what Akarrin found, but I think Escaralde and the others intend to use it to prod the Hall toward something." Peering at the dark dregs floating in a few drops in the bottom of the pewter cup, Egwene sighed.

ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi ðɛɹ, tu, ən naʊ ʃi wəɾ əv tə feɪs ðə sɪɾɝz wɪð ə hɛdeɪk ən ðəɾ ɑfəl teɪst ɪn əɹ maʊθ. pɝhæps ʃi kəd kɔl ɪɾ ə pɛnəns fəɹ wʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə də tə ðə hɔl.

She would have to be there, too, and now she would have to face the Sitters with a headache and that awful taste in her mouth. Perhaps she could call it a penance for what she was going to do to the Hall.

tʃæptɝ naɪntin

CHAPTER 19

sɝpɹaɪzəz baɪ kʌstəm, ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz ɪnfɔɹmd ə ðə hɔl sɪɾɪŋ, jɛt nʌθɪŋ sɛd ðeɪ hæd tə weɪt fəɹ əɹ bɪfɔɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɛʃən, wɪtʃ mɛn ðət taɪm maɪt bi ʃɔɹt. ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə lip tə hɝ fiɾ ən mɑɹtʃ stʃɹeɪt tə ðə bɪɡ pəvɪljən bɪfɔɹ mɔɹiə ən ði ʌðɝ tu kəd spɹɪŋ wʌtɛvɝ sɝpɹaɪz ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd. sɝpɹaɪzəz ɪn ðə hɔl wɝ sɛldəm ɡʊd. sɝpɹaɪzəz jə lɝn əbaʊt leɪt wɝ wɝs.

Surprises By custom, the Amyrlin was informed of the Hall sitting, yet nothing said they had to wait for her before starting the session, which meant that time might be short. Egwene wanted to leap to her feet and march straight to the big pavilion before Moria and the other two could spring whatever surprise they intended. Surprises in the Hall were seldom good. Surprises you learned about late were worse.

stɪl, pɹoʊɾəkɔlz ðət wɝ lɔ, nɑt kʌstəm, hæd tə bi fɑloʊd fəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn ɛntɝɪŋ ðə hɔl, soʊ ʃi ɹɪmeɪnd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz ən sɛn sɪuən tə fɛtʃ ʃi-ɹiəm soʊ ʃi kəd bi ənaʊns pɹɑpɝli baɪ ðə kipɝ ə ðə kɹɑnəkəlz. sɪuən hæd toʊld əɹ ðət wɑz ɹɪli ə mæɾɝ ʌv wɔɹnɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz ə hɝ pɹɛzəns - ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz mæɾɝz ðeɪ maɪt wɑnə dɪskʌs wɪθaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn noʊɪŋ - ən ʃi hæd nɑt saʊndəɾ ɪntaɪɝli əz ɪf ʃi wɝ meɪkɪŋ ə dʒoʊk.

Still, protocols that were law, not custom, had to be followed for the Amyrlin entering the Hall, so she remained where she was and sent Siuan to fetch She-riam so she could be announced properly by the Keeper of the Chronicles. Siuan had told her that was really a matter of warning the Sitters of her presence - there were always matters they might want to discuss without the Amyrlin knowing - and she had not sounded entirely as if she were making a joke.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə hɔl əntɪl ʃi kəɾ ɛntɝ. tæmpɪŋ daʊn əɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns, ʃi pɹɑpt əɹ hɛɾ ɑn əɹ hænz ən məsɑʒd əɹ tɛmpəlz əz ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹiɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ə ði ədʒɑ ɹɪpɔɹts. dɪspaɪt ðə vaɪl "ti," əɹ pɝhæps kəz ʌv ɪt, hɝ hɛdeɪk meɪd ðə wɝdz ʃɪmɝ ɑn ðə peɪdʒ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi blɪŋkt, ən æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝ tu dɪd nɑt hɛlp. noʊ sunɝ dɪd sɪuən dɪpɑɹt ðən æneɪjə tɔs bæk əɹ kloʊk, sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn ðə stul sɪuən hæd veɪkeɪɾəd - ɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə lɝtʃ ʌndɝ hɝ, ənivən lɛɡz əɹ noʊ - ən bɪɡæn tə spɛkjəleɪɾ ɑn wʌt mɔɹiə ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ æftɝ.

In any case, there was no point in going to the Hall until she could enter. Tamping down her impatience, she propped her head on her hands and massaged her temples as she tried to read a little more of the Ajah reports. Despite the vile "tea," or perhaps because of it, her headache made the words shimmer on the page every time she blinked, and Anaiya and the other two did not help. No sooner did Siuan depart than Anaiya tossed back her cloak, settling on the stool Siuan had vacated - it did not seem to lurch under her, uneven legs or no - and began to speculate on what Moria and the others were after.

ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə flaɪɾi wʊmən, soʊ hɝ vɛntʃɝz wɝ kwaɪt kənstʃɹeɪnd ɡɪvən ðə sɝkəmstænsəz.

She was not a flighty woman, so her ventures were quite constrained given the circumstances.

kənstʃɹeɪnd, bʌt noʊ lɛs əpsɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðæt.

Constrained, but no less upsetting for that.

"fɹaɪɾənd pipəl də sɪli θɪŋz, mʌðɝ, ivən ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi mɝmɝd, pleɪsɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz, "bʌɾ ət lis jə kən bi ʃʊɹ mɔɹiə wɪl bi fɝm əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾə, ət list ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn. ʃi leɪz ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u daɪɾ æftɝ sɪuən wɑz dɪpoʊzd ɹaɪɾ əɾ ɪleɪɾəz fit. mɔɹiə wɑns ɪleɪɾə bɝtʃt fəɹ ɛvɹi sɪŋɡəl dɛθ bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɡoʊz tə ðə hɛdzmən. ə hɑɹd wʊmən, hɑɹɾɝ ðən ləleɪn ɪn səm weɪz.

"Frightened people do silly things, Mother, even Aes Sedai," she murmured, placing her hands on her knees, "but at least you can be sure Moria will be firm about Elaida, at least in the long run. She lays every sister who died after Siuan was deposed right at Elaida's feet. Moria wants Elaida birched for every single death before she goes to the headsman. A hard woman, harder than Lelaine in some ways.
