tʌfɝ, ɛniweɪ. ʃi woʊn skɹupəl ət θɪŋz ðət maɪt meɪk ləleɪn bɔk. aɪm vɛɹi mʌtʃ əfɹeɪd ʃɪl pɹɛs fəɹ ən əsɔlt ɑn ðə sɪɾi əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ muvɪŋ soʊ oʊpənli, ɑn sətʃ ə skeɪl, ðən bɛɾɝ ə wundəd taʊɝ ðæts hoʊl ðən ə taʊɝ dɪvaɪɾəd. ət list, aɪ fɪɹ ðæts haʊ mɔɹiə meɪ si θɪŋz. æftɝ ɔl, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ wi wɑnə əvɔɪd sɪstɝz kɪlɪŋ sɪstɝz, ɪt wʊdn bi ðə fɝs taɪm. ðə taʊɝ əz læstəɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ən hil fɹəm mɛni wunz. wi kən hil fɹəm ðɪs wʌn, tu." æneɪjəz vɔɪs suɾəd əɹ feɪs, wɔɹm ən peɪʃən ən kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, bʌt meɪkɪŋ ðoʊz ɹɪmɑɹks ɪt sim laɪk fɪŋɡɝneɪlz skɹitʃɪŋ daʊn ə slæt. laɪt, fəɹ ɔl æneɪjə seɪɪŋ ðɪs wɑz wʌt ʃi fɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə mɔɹiə, ʃi simd mʌtʃ ɪn əkɔɹd wɪð ðə sɛntəməns. ʃi wɑz dɪlɪbɝɪt, ənflæpəbəl, ən nɛvɝ kɛɹləs wɪð wɝdz. ɪf ʃi feɪvɝɾ ən əsɔlt, haʊ mɛni ʌðɝz dɪd, tu? əz juʒəwəl, maɪɹɛl wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bʌt kənstʃɹeɪnd. mɝkjʊɹiəl ən faɪɝi dɪskɹaɪbd əɹ bɛst. ʃi wəd nɑt noʊ peɪʃəns ɪf ɪt bɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə noʊz. ʃi peɪs bæk ən fɔɹθ, əz mʌtʃ əz ðə kɑnfaɪnz ə ðə tɛn əlaʊd, kɪkɪŋ əɹ dip-ɡɹin skɝts ən səmtaɪmz kɪkɪŋ wʌn ə ðə bɹaɪt kʊʃənz paɪld əɡɛns ðə wɔl bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə meɪk ənʌðɝ ɹaʊnd. "ɪf mɔɹiə ɪz fɹaɪɾənd ɪnʌf tə pɹɛs fəɹ ən əsɔlt, ðən ʃiz fɹaɪɾənd aʊɾ ə hɝ wɪts. eɪ taʊɝ tu wundəd tə stæn əloʊn woʊn bi eɪbəl tə feɪs ðə fɔɹseɪkən əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls. mɑlɪn ɪz u ʃəd kənsɝn ju. ʃiz ɔlweɪz pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt ðət tɑɹmən ɡdən kəd bi əpɑn əs ɛni deɪ.

Tougher, anyway. She won't scruple at things that might make Lelaine balk. I'm very much afraid she will press for an assault on the city as soon as possible. If the Forsaken are moving so openly, on such a scale, then better a wounded Tower that's whole than a Tower divided. At least, I fear that's how Moria may see things. After all, however much we want to avoid sisters killing sisters, it wouldn't be the first time. The Tower has lasted a long time, and healed from many wounds. We can heal from this one, too." Anaiya's voice suited her face, warm and patient and comforting, but making those remarks it seemed like fingernails screeching down a slat. Light, for all Anaiya saying this was what she feared out of Moria, she seemed much in accord with the sentiments. She was deliberate, unflappable, and never careless with words. If she favored an assault, how many others did, too? As usual, Myrelle was anything but constrained. Mercurial and fiery described her best. She would not know patience if it bit her on the nose. She paced back and forth, as much as the confines of the tent allowed, kicking her deep-green skirts and sometimes kicking one of the bright cushions piled against the wall before turning to make another round. "If Moria is frightened enough to press for an assault, then she's frightened out of her wits. A Tower too wounded to stand alone won't be able to face the Forsaken or anyone else. Malind is who should concern you. She's always pointing out that Tarmon Gai'don could be upon us any day.

aɪv hɝɾ əɹ seɪ ðət wʌt wi fɛl kəd wɛl əv bɪn ði oʊpənɪŋ bloʊz ðə læs bæɾəl. ɔ ðəɾ ɪt maɪt hæpən hɪɹ, nɛkst. wɛɹ bɛɾɝ fəɹ ðə ʃædoʊ tə stʃɹaɪk ðən tɑɹ vəlɑn? mɑlɪn əz nɛvɝ bɪn əfɹeɪd tə meɪk hɑɹd tʃɔɪsəz, əɹ tə ɹitʃɹit wən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt nɛsəsɛɹi. ʃi wəɾ əbændən tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ðə taʊɝ ət wʌns ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wəd pɹəzɝv ət list səm ʌv əs fəɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən. ʃɪl pɹəpoʊz lɪftɪŋ ðə sidʒ, fliɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən kæn faɪn əs əntɪl wɝ ɹɛɾi tə stʃɹaɪk bæk.

I've heard her say that what we felt could well have been the opening blows the Last Battle. AW that it might happen here, next. Where better for the Shadow to strike than Tar Valon? Malind has never been afraid to make hard choices, or to retreat when she thought it necessary. She would abandon Tar Valon and the Tower at once if she thought it would preserve at least some of us for Tarmon Gai'don. She will propose lifting the siege, fleeing somewhere the Forsaken can't find us until we're ready to strike back.

ɪf ʃi pʊts ðə kwɛstʃən tə ðə hɔl ɪn ðə ɹaɪt weɪ, ʃi maɪɾ ivən ɡɛt ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kənsɛnsəs ɪn səpɔɹt." ðə vɛɹi θɔt meɪd ðə wɝdz dæns hɑɹɾɝ ɑn ðə peɪdʒ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɡwin.

If she puts the question to the Hall in the right way, she might even get the greater consensus in support." The very thought made the words dance harder on the page in front of Egwene.

mɔɹvɹɪn, hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs ʌnɹilɛntɪŋ, sɪmpli plæntəd fɪsts ɑn æmpəl hɪps ən mɛɾ itʃ sədʒɛstʃən wɪð ə kɝɾ ænsɝ. "wi doʊnt noʊ ɪnʌf jɛt tə bi ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ðə fɔɹseɪkən," ən "ju kænt noʊ əntɪl ʃi sɛz." "pɝhæps ɪt wɑz, ən pɝhæps nɑt," ən "sʌpəzɪʃən ɪzən ɛvəɾəns." ɪt wɑz sɛd ʃi wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪt wɑz mɔɹnɪŋ tɪl ʃi sɔ ðə sʌn fəɹ hɝsɛlf. hɝ fɝm vɔɪs bɹʊk noʊ nɑnsɛns, ɪspɛʃli dʒʌmps tə kənkluʒənz. ɪt wɑz nɑt suðɪŋ tə ən eɪkɪŋ hɛd, iðɝ. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əpoʊzɪŋ ðə sədʒɛstʃənz, ɹɪli, dʒʌs kipɪŋ ən oʊpən maɪnd. ən oʊpən maɪn kəd ɡoʊ iðɝ weɪ wən ɪt keɪm daʊn tə ðə stɪkɪŋ pɔɪnt. ɛɡwin slæp ði ɪmbɔs foʊldɝ ʃʌɾ ɑn ðə ɹɪpɔɹts wɪð ə laʊd smæk. bɪtwin ðə dɪsɡʌstɪŋ teɪst ɑn əɹ tʌŋ ən ðə ʃɑɹp θɹəb ɪn əɹ hɛd - nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðɛɹ ɪnsɛsən vɔɪsəz! - ʃi kəd nɑt kip əɹ pleɪs tə ɹiɾ ɛniweɪ. ðə θɹi sɪstɝz lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ʃi hæd meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ lɔŋ əɡoʊ ðət ʃi wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, bʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ʃoʊ tɛmpɝ. oʊðz ə fiəlti əɹ noʊ oʊðz ə fiəlti, ə jʌŋ wʊmən dɪspleɪɪŋ tɛmpɝ wɑz tu izi tə dɪsmɪs əz sʌlki. wɪtʃ oʊnli meɪɾ əɹ æŋɡɹiɝ, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əɹ hɛd hɝt mɔɹ, wɪtʃ. . . .

Morvrin, her round face unrelenting, simply planted fists on ample hips and met each suggestion with a curt answer. "We don't know enough yet to be sure it was the Forsaken," and "You can't know until she says." "Perhaps it was, and perhaps not," and "Supposition isn't evidence." It was said she would not believe it was morning till she saw the sun for herself. Her firm voice brooked no nonsense, especially jumps to conclusions. It was not soothing to an aching head, either. She was not opposing the suggestions, really, just keeping an open mind. An open mind could go either way when it came down to the sticking point. Egwene slapped the embossed folder shut on the reports with a loud smack. Between the disgusting taste on her tongue and the sharp throb in her head - not to mention their incessant voices! - she could not keep her place to read anyway. The three sisters looked at her in surprise. She had made it clear long ago that she was in charge, but she tried not to show temper. Oaths of fealty or no oaths of fealty, a young woman displaying temper was too easy to dismiss as sulky. Which only made her angrier, which made her head hurt more, which. . . .

"aɪv weɪɾəd lɔŋ ɪnʌf," ʃi sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ən ɛfɝt tə kip əɹ vɔɪs smuð. hɝ hɛd ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə slaɪɾ ɛdʒ ə ʃɑɹpnəs ɛniweɪ. pɝhæps ʃɛɹiəm θɔt ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə miɾ əɹ ət ðə hɔl.

"I've waited long enough," she said, making an effort to keep her voice smooth. Her head gave it a slight edge of sharpness anyway. Perhaps Sheriam thought she was supposed to meet her at the Hall.

ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ kloʊk, ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə koʊld waɪl stɪl swɪŋɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən mɔɹvɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ɪn əɹ weɪk. əkʌmpəniɪŋ əɹ tə ðə hɔl maɪt sim ə lɪɾəl laɪk ðeɪ wɝ əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, ən ʃi səspɛktəd ðəɾ ivən mɔɹvɹɪn wɑz iɡɝ tə hɪɹ wʌɾ ækæɹən hæd tə ɹipɔɹɾ ən wʌt mɔɹiə ən ðə ɹɛst ɪntɛndəd tə fæʃən fɹəm ɪt. nʌθɪŋ tu dɪfəkəl tə dil wɪð, ɛɡwin hoʊpt, nʌθɪŋ laɪk wʌɾ æneɪjə ən maɪɹɛl θɔt. ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, ʃi kəd tʃɹaɪ əplaɪɪŋ ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ, bʌɾ ivən ɪf ðət wɑz səksɛsfəl, ɹulɪŋ baɪ iɾɪkt hæɾ ɪts dɪsədvæntɪdʒɪz. wən pipəl hæd tə oʊbeɪ jə ɪn wʌn θɪŋ, ðeɪ ɔlweɪz faʊnd weɪz tə ɹɪɡəl əweɪ ɑn ʌðɝz, ən ðə mɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹs tə oʊbeɪ, ðə mɔɹ pleɪsəz ðeɪ faʊn fəɹ ɹɪəlɪŋ əweɪ. ɪt wɑz ə nætʃɹəl bæləns jə kəd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp. wɝs, ʃi hæd lɝn dʒʌs haʊ ədɪktɪv ɪt wɑz tə hæv pipəl dʒʌmp wən ʃi spoʊk. jə keɪm tə teɪk ɪɾ əz ðə nætʃɹəl weɪ ʌv θɪŋz, ən ðən wən ðeɪ feɪl tə dʒʌmp, jə wɝ kɑɾ ɑn ðə ɹɔŋ fʊt. bɪsaɪdz, wɪð əɹ hɛd paʊndɪŋ - ɪt wɑz paʊndɪŋ, naʊ, nɑt θɹɑbɪŋ, ðoʊ pɝhæps nɑɾ əz ʃɑɹpli - wɪð əɹ hɛd, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə snæp əɾ ɛniwʌn u lʊkt əɾ əɹ kɹɔswaɪz, ən ivən wən pipəl hæd tə swɑloʊ ɪt, ðət nɛvɝ wɛn daʊn wɛl.

Gathering her cloak, she strode out into the cold while still swinging it around her shoulders, and Morvrin and the other two hesitated only a moment before following in her wake. Accompanying her to the Hall might seem a little like they were her entourage, but they were supposed to be watching her, and she suspected that even Morvrin was eager to hear what Akarrin had to report and what Moria and the rest intended to fashion from it. Nothing too difficult to deal with, Egwene hoped, nothing like what Anaiya and Myrelle thought. If necessary, she could try applying the Law of War, but even if that was successful, ruling by edict had its disadvantages. When people had to obey you in one thing, they always found ways to wriggle away on others, and the more they were forced to obey, the more places they found for wriggling away. It was a natural balance you could not escape. Worse, she had learned just how addictive it was to have people jump when she spoke. You came to take it as the natural way of things, and then when they failed to jump, you were caught on the wrong foot. Besides, with her head pounding - it was pounding, now, not throbbing, though perhaps not as sharply - with her head, she was ready to snap at anyone who looked at her crosswise, and even when people had to swallow it, that never went down well.

ðə sʌn stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, ə ɡoʊldən bɔl ɪn ə blu skaɪ wɪð ə skæɾɝɪŋ ʌv waɪt klaʊdz, bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ, oʊnli wɑn ʃædoʊz ən ə ɡlɪɾɝ tə ðə snoʊ wɛɹɛvɝ ɪt ɹɪmeɪn əntʃɹæmpəld. ði ɛɹ fɛlt əz tʃɪl əz ɪt hæd baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɛɡwin ɪɡnɔɹd ðə koʊld, ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ ɪt tʌtʃ hɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə dɛd cʊɾə bɪn ʌnəwɛɹ, wɪð ɛvɹiwʌnz bɹɛθ mɪstɪŋ waɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ðə mɪddeɪ mil, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv fiɾɪŋ soʊ mɛni nɑvəsɪz ət wʌns, soʊ ɛɡwin ən əɹ ɛskɔɹt stɪl muv θɹu ə weɪv ʌv waɪt-klæd wɪmən lipɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ ən stɑɹɾɪŋ tə kɝtsi ɪn ðə stʃɹit. ʃi sɛt sətʃ ə peɪs ðət ðeɪ wɝ juʒəwəli pæs bɪfɔɹ ðə nɑts ə nɑvəsɪz kəd mɔɹ ðən spɹɛd ðɛɹ skɝts.

The sun stood straight overhead, a golden ball in a blue sky with a scattering of white clouds, but it gave no warmth, only wan shadows and a glitter to the snow wherever it remained untrampled. The air felt as chill as it had by the river. Egwene ignored the cold, refused to let it touch her, but only the dead could have been unaware, with everyone's breath misting white in front of their faces. It was time for the midday meal, yet there was no possibility of feeding so many novices at once, so Egwene and her escort still moved through a wave of white-clad women leaping out of their way and starting to curtsy in the street. She set such a pace that they were usually past before the knots of novices could more than spread their skirts.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə lɔŋ weɪ, wɪð oʊnli fɔɹ pleɪsəz ðət ðeɪ niɾəd tə weɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə mʌɾi stʃɹits.

It was not a long way, with only four places that they needed to wade across the muddy streets.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn tɔk ʌv wʊɾən bɹɪdʒəz, tɔl ɪnʌf tə ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ, bʌt bɹɪdʒəz sədʒɛstəɾ ə pɝmənəns tə ðə kæmp ðət noʊ wʌn wɑntəd. ivən ðə sɪstɝz u spoʊk ə ðɛm nɛvɝ pɹɛs tə hæv əm bɪlt.

There had been talk of wooden bridges, tall enough to ride under, but bridges suggested a permanence to the camp that no one wanted. Even the sisters who spoke of them never pressed to have them built.

wɪtʃ lɛft weɪɾɪŋ sloʊli, ən teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ tə kip jəɹ skɝts ən kloʊk haɪ ɪf jə wɝ nɑt tə ɝaɪv fɪlθi tə jəɹ niz. ət lis ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ kɹaʊdz vænɪʃt əz ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt ðə hɔl. ðət stʊɾ əloʊn əz ɔlweɪz, əɹ nɪɹli soʊ.

Which left wading slowly, and taking care to keep your skirts and cloak high if you were not to arrive filthy to your knees. At least the remaining crowds vanished as they approached the Hall. That stood alone as always, or nearly so.

naɪsaʊ ən kɑɹlɪnjə wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɪɡ kænvəs pəvɪljən wɪð ɪts pætʃt saɪd kɝɾənz, ðə taɪni jɛloʊ fɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ ʌndɝlɪp wɪð əɹ tiθ ən aɪɪŋ ɛɡwin æŋkʃəsli. kɑɹlɪnjə wɑz kɑmnəs ɪtsɛlf, kul-aɪd, hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst. ɪksɛp ðət ʃi hæd fɝɡɑɾən əɹ kloʊk, mʌd steɪn ðə skɹoʊlɪmbɹɔɪɾɝd hɛm ə hɝ peɪl skɝt, ən əɹ kæp ə dɑɹk kɝlz bædli niɾəd ə koʊm.

Nisao and Carlinya were already waiting in front of the big canvas pavilion with its patched side curtains, the tiny Yellow fretting her underlip with her teeth and eyeing Egwene anxiously. Carlinya was calmness itself, cool-eyed, hands folded at her waist. Except that she had forgotten her cloak, mud stained the scrollembroidered hem of her pale skirt, and her cap of dark curls badly needed a comb.

meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ kɝɾəsiz, ðə pɛɹ dʒɔɪn æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝ tu, ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns bɪhaɪn ɛɡwin. ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm mɝmɝd sɔfli, ðə snætʃɪz ðəɾ ɛɡwin kɑɾ ɪnɑkjuəs, əbaʊt ðə wɛðɝ, əɹ haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə weɪt. ðɪs wɑz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ əm tə sim tu kloʊsli əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð hɝ.

Making their courtesies, the pair joined Anaiya and the other two, a little distance behind Egwene. The lot of them murmured softly, the snatches that Egwene caught innocuous, about the weather, or how long they might have to wait. This was no place for them to seem too closely associated with her.

bioʊnɪn keɪm daʊn ðə wɔk əɾ ə ɹʌn, hɝ hɝid bɹɛθ mɪstɪŋ, ən skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin bɪfɔɹ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ði ʌðɝz. ðə stʃɹeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ blu-ɡɹeɪ aɪz wɑz ivən mɔɹ əpɛɹən ðən ɝliɝ.

Beonin came down the walk at a run, her hurried breath misting, and skidded to a halt, staring at Egwene before joining the others. The strain around her blue-gray eyes was even more apparent than earlier.

pɝhæps ʃi θɔt ðɪs wəɾ əfɛkt əɹ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz. bʌt ʃi nu ðə tɔks wəd bi ə ʃæm, dʒʌst ə plɔɪ tə ɡeɪn taɪm. ɛɡwin kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ bɹiðɪŋ ən pɹæktəs nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪzəz, jɛt nʌn ʌv ɪt hɛlpt əɹ hɛd. ɪt nɛvɝ dɪd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə ʃɛɹiəm əmʌŋ ðə tɛns ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli əloʊn ɑn ðə wɔkweɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə pəvɪljən. ækæɹən ən ðə faɪv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz u hæd ɡɔn wɪð hɝ, wʌn fɹəm itʃ ədʒɑ, wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə klʌstɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɛntʃɹəns. moʊst ɔfɝd kɝtsiz tə ɛɡwin dɪstʃɹæktɪdli, jɛt kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd bɪn wɔɹn tə seɪ nʌθɪŋ tə ɛniwʌn əntɪl ðeɪ spoʊk bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl. ɛɡwin kəd sɪmpli hæv dɪmændəd ðɛɹ ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn ðə spɑt, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ maɪɾ ivən əv ɡɪvən ɪt, tə ði æmɪɝlɪn. laɪkli ðeɪ wəd hæv. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ən æmɪɝlɪnz ɹileɪʃənz wɪð ði ədʒəz wɝ ɔlweɪz dɛləkət, ɔfən ɪnkluɾɪŋ ði ədʒɑ ʃi hæd bɪn ɹeɪz fɹʌm. nɪɹli əz dɛləkəɾ əz ɹileɪʃənz wɪð ðə hɔl. ɛɡwin meɪd hɝsɛlf smaɪl ən baʊ hɝ hɛd ɡɹeɪʃəsli. ɪf ʃi ɡɹɪɾɪd əɹ tiθ bɪhaɪn ðət smaɪl, wɛl, ðət hɛlp kip əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt.

Perhaps she thought this would affect her negotiations. But she knew the talks would be a sham, just a ploy to gain time. Egwene controlled her breathing and practiced novice exercises, yet none of it helped her head. It never did. There was no sign of Sheriam among the tents in any direction, but they were not precisely alone on the walkway outside the pavilion. Akarrin and the five other sisters who had gone with her, one from each Ajah, were waiting in a cluster on the other side of the entrance. Most offered curtsies to Egwene distractedly, yet kept their distance. Perhaps they had been warned to say nothing to anyone until they spoke before the Hall. Egwene could simply have demanded their report on the spot, of course. They might even have given it, to the Amyrlin. Likely they would have. On the other hand, an Amyrlin's relations with the Ajahs were always delicate, often including the Ajah she had been raised from. Nearly as delicate as relations with the Hall. Egwene made herself smile and bow her head graciously. If she gritted her teeth behind that smile, well, that helped keep her mouth shut.

nɑɾ ɔl ə ðə sɪstɝz simd əwɛɹ ə hɝ pɹɛzəns. ækæɹən, slɛndɝ ɪn pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊl ən ə kloʊk wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli ɪlæbɹət ɡɹin ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, nɑɾɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf naʊ ən ðɛn. əpɛɹənli ʃi wɑz pɹæktəsɪŋ wʌt ʃi wəd seɪ ɪnsaɪd. ækæɹən wɑz nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən sɪuən ɪf əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn ʌðɝ ə ðə sɪks, θɝvə, ə slɪm wʊmən ɪn jɛloʊ-slæʃt ɹaɪɾɪŋ skɝts ən ə kloʊk ɛdʒd wɪð jɛloʊ, stʊɾ ivən əz haɪ əz ʃi. ðət wɑz ə dɪstʃɹɛsɪŋ mɛʒɝ ə dʒʌs haʊ fɹaɪɾənd ðə sɪstɝz wɝ baɪ ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ bikən ə seɪaɪdɑɹ. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ʃʊɾə stɛp fɔɹwɝd fəɹ ðə tæsk ðət hæd bɪn ɡɪvən tə ðiz, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ækæɹən hɝsɛlf, zil hæd bɪn noʊɾəbli lækɪŋ. hɝ kəmpænjənz stɪl əpɪɹd lɛs ðən ɪnθuziæstɪk. ʃænə nɔɹməli meɪnteɪn ə dip ɹɪzɝv dɪspaɪɾ aɪz ðət meɪɾ əɹ əpɪɹ kɑnstənli stɑɹɾəld, bʌt naʊ ðeɪ simd ɹɛɾi tə kʌm aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd wɪð wɝi. ʃi pɪɹɾ ət ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə hɔl, kloʊzd ɔf baɪ hɛvi flæps, ən əɹ hænz fɪɾəld wɪð əɹ kloʊk əz ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt kip əm stɪl. ɹikoʊ, ə staʊɾ ɝæfɛlɪn blu, kɛpt əɹ aɪz daʊn, bʌt ðə sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn əɹ lɔŋ dɑɹk hɛɹ tʃaɪm feɪnli əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ kaʊl. oʊnli θɝvəz lɔŋ-noʊz feɪs wɔɹ ə lʊk ʌv æbsəlut sɝɛnəɾi, kəmplitli ʌnpɝtɝbd ən ənʃeɪkəbəl, jɛt ðəɾ ɪn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ə bæd saɪn. ðə jɛloʊ sɪstɝ wɑz ɪksaɪɾəbəl baɪ neɪtʃɝ. wʌt hæd ðeɪ sin? wʌt wɝ mɔɹiə ən ði ʌðɝ tu sɪɾɝz æftɝ? ɛɡwin kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns; ðə hɔl pleɪnli wɑz nɑt sɪɾɪŋ jɛt. ɪt wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ, bʌt sɛvɹəl sɪɾɝz stʃɹoʊl pæst əɹ ən ɪndə ðə bɪɡ pəvɪljən, nʌn hɝiɪŋ. sæliɾə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ɪf ʃi maɪt spik, bʌt ðən oʊnli dɪpt əɹ niz bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ən swipɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. kweɪmɛsə pɪɹd daʊn əɹ ʃɑɹp noʊz əɾ ɛɡwin waɪl meɪkɪŋ əɹ kɝtsi, ən pɪɹd daʊn əɹ noʊz waɪl stʌɾiɪŋ æneɪjə ən ði ʌðɝz bɹifli, bʌt ðɛn, ðə slɪm ɡɹeɪ pɪɹd daʊn əɹ noʊz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn. ʃi wɑz nɑt tɔl, bʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə sim soʊ. bɛɹænə, feɪs ə mæsk ə hɔtinəs ən bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz əz koʊld əz ðə snoʊ, pɔz tə ɔfɝ kul kɝɾəsiz tə ɛɡwin ən fɹaʊn əɾ ækæɹən. æftɝ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, pɝhæps ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ ækæɹən dɪd nɑɾ ivən si hɝ, ʃi smuðd əɹ sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd waɪt skɝts, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪt, ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl əlɔŋ əɹ ɑɹmz soʊ ðə waɪt fɹɪnʒ hʌŋ dʒʌst soʊ, ən ɡlaɪɾɪd θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi flæps əz ðoʊ ʃi dʒʌs hæpən tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən. ɔl θɹi wɝ əmʌŋ ðə sɪɾɝz sɪuən hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊɾ əz tu jʌŋ. əz wɝ mɑlɪn ən ɛskɹɑldi. bʌt mɔɹiə hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd ən θɝɾi jɪɹz. laɪt, sɪuən hæɾ əɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ kənspɪɹəsiz ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ!

Not all of the sisters seemed aware of her presence. Akarrin, slender in plain brown wool and a cloak with surprisingly elaborate green embroidery, was staring at nothing, nodding to herself now and then. Apparently she was practicing what she would say inside. Akarrin was not strong in the Power, little more than Siuan if at all, but only one other of the six, Therva, a slim woman in yellow-slashed riding skirts and a cloak edged with yellow, stood even as high as she. That was a distressing measure of just how frightened the sisters were by that strange beacon of saidar. The strongest should have stepped forward for the task that had been given to these, but except for Akarrin herself, zeal had been notably lacking. Her companions still appeared less than enthusiastic. Shana normally maintained a deep reserve despite eyes that made her appear constantly startled, but now they seemed ready to come out of her head with worry. She peered at the entrance to the Hall, closed off by heavy flaps, and her hands fiddled with her cloak as if she could not keep them still. Reiko, a stout Arafellin Blue, kept her eyes down, but the silver bells in her long dark hair chimed faintly as if she were shaking her head inside her cowl. Only Therva's long-nosed face wore a look of absolute serenity, completely unperturbed and unshakable, yet that in itself was a bad sign. The Yellow sister was excitable by nature. What had they seen? What were Moria and the other two Sitters after? Egwene controlled her impatience; the Hall plainly was not sitting yet. It was gathering, but several Sitters strolled past her and into the big pavilion, none hurrying. Salita hesitated as if she might speak, but then only dipped her knees before raising her yellow-fringed shawl onto her shoulders and sweeping inside. Kwamesa peered down her sharp nose at Egwene while making her curtsy, and peered down her nose while studying Anaiya and the others briefly, but then, the slim Gray peered down her nose at everyone. She was not tall, but she tried to seem so. Berana, face a mask of haughtiness and big brown eyes as cold as the snow, paused to offer cool courtesies to Egwene and frown at Akarrin. After a long moment, perhaps realizing that Akarrin did not even see her, she smoothed her silver-embroidered white skirts, which did not need it, adjusted her shawl along her arms so the white fringe hung just so, and glided through the entry flaps as though she just happened to be going in that direction. All three were among the Sitters Siuan had pointed out as too young. As were Malind and Escaralde. But Moria had been Aes Sedai for a hundred and thirty years. Light, Siuan had her looking for conspiracies in everything!

dʒʌst əz ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðəɾ əɹ hɛd wəɾ ɪksploʊd fɹəm fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ɪf nɑt fɹəm əɹ hɛdeɪk, ʃɛɹiəm sʌɾənli əpɪɹd, haɪkɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ən skɝts waɪl hæf-ɹʌnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə dɝɾi slʌʃ ə ðə stʃɹit. "aɪm tɛɹəbli sɑɹi, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli, tʃænəlɪŋ hɝidli tə klin ɔf ðə mʌd ʃi hæd splæʃt ɑn hɝsɛlf. ɪt fɛl tə ðə wɔkweɪ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ paʊɾɝ wən ʃi twɪtʃt əɹ skɝts.

Just as Egwene began to think that her head would explode from frustration if not from her headache, Sheriam suddenly appeared, hiking her cloak and skirts while half-running across the dirty slush of the street. "I'm terribly sorry, Mother," she said breathlessly, channeling hurriedly to clean off the mud she had splashed on herself. It fell to the walkway in a dry powder when she twitched her skirts.

"aɪ . . . aɪ hɝd ðət ðə hɔl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ, ən aɪ nu jə wəd bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi, soʊ aɪ keɪm əz fæst əz aɪ kʊd. ɪm vɛɹi sɑɹi." soʊ sɪuən wɑz stɪl sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ hɝ. "jɔɹ hɪɹ naʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli.

"I . . . I heard that the Hall was sitting, and I knew you would be looking for me, so I came as fast as I could. I'm very sorry." So Siuan was still searching for her. "You're here now," Egwene said firmly.

ðə wʊmən mʌst əv bɪn tʃɹuli ʌpsɛt tə ɔfɝ əpɑlədʒiz ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝz, ækæɹən ən əɹ kəmpænjənz mɔɹ ðən æneɪjə ən ðə ɹɛst. ivən wən pipəl nu bɛɾɝ, ðeɪ tɛndəd tə teɪk jə fəɹ wʌt jə əpɪɹd tə bi, ən ðə kipɝ ʃəd nɑt bi sin əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ ən ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz. ʃʊɹli ʃi nu ðæt. "ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən ənaʊns mi." dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃɛɹiəm pʊʃt bæk ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk, ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ nɛɹoʊ blu stoʊl, ən stɛp θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi flæps. hɝ vɔɪs ɹæŋ aʊt klɪɹli ɪn ðə ɹɪtʃuəl fɹeɪzəz. "ʃi kʌmz, ʃi kʌmz. . . ."

The woman must have been truly upset to offer apologies in front of the others, Akarrin and her companions more than Anaiya and the rest. Even when people knew better, they tended to take you for what you appeared to be, and the Keeper should not be seen apologizing and wringing her hands. Surely she knew that. "Go ahead and announce me." Drawing a deep breath, Sheriam pushed back the hood of her cloak, adjusted her narrow blue stole, and stepped through the entry flaps. Her voice rang out clearly in the ritual phrases. "She comes, she comes. . . ."

ɛɡwin bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ tə fɪnɪʃ wɪð " . . . ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit," bɪfɔɹ stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn θɹu ðə ɹɪŋ ə bɹeɪʒɝz ən stænd-læmps ðət ɹɪm ðə pəvɪljənz wɔlz. ðə stænd-læmps ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd laɪt, ən ðə bɹeɪʒɝz, ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf ə sɛn ə lævəndɝ tədeɪ, wɔɹm ðə hoʊl speɪs. noʊ wʌn wɪʃt tə hæv tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə koʊld wən ʃi kəd fil ɹil wɔɹmθ.

Egwene barely waited for her to finish with " . . . the Flame of Tar Valon, the Amyrlin Seat," before striding in through the ring of braziers and stand-lamps that rimmed the pavilion's walls. The stand-lamps gave a good light, and the braziers, giving off a scent of lavender today, warmed the whole space. No one wished to have to ignore the cold when she could feel real warmth.

ði ɝeɪnʒmənt ə ðə pəvɪljən fɑloʊɾ eɪntʃən ɹulz, mɑɾəfaɪd oʊnli slaɪtli tə əlaʊ fəɹ ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɑt miɾɪŋ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝkjəlɝ tʃeɪmbɝ kɔl ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ. ət ðə fɑɹ ɛnd, ə sɪmpəl ɪf wɛl pɑlɪʃt bɛntʃ stʊɾ ətɑp ə bɑks-laɪk plætfɔɹm kʌvɝd wɪð klɔθ stʃɹaɪpt ɪn ðə sɛvən kʌlɝz ə ði ədʒəz. ðəɾ ən ðə stoʊl ɝaʊn ɛɡwinz nɛk wɝ ʃʊɹli ði oʊnli pleɪsəz ɪn ðə kæmp wɛɹ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ hæɾ ɛni ɹɛpɹəzɛnteɪʃən. səm bluz hæd wɑntəd ðə kʌlɝ ɹimuvd, sɪns ɪleɪɾə əpɛɹənli hæd hæd ði æktʃəwəl θɹoʊn kɔl ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ɹipeɪntəɾ ən ə stoʊl woʊvən wɪθaʊt blu, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd dʌɡ ɪn əɹ hilz. ɪf ʃi wɑz tə bi ʌv ɔl ədʒəz ən nʌn, ðən ʃi wəd bi ʌv ɔl ədʒəz. daʊn ðə bɹaɪt leɪɝd kɑɹpəts ðət sɝvd əz ə ɡɹaʊnd-klɔθ, tu laɪnz ə bɛntʃɪz slæntəɾ əweɪ fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹəns ɪn ɡɹups ə θɹi, sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp klɔθ-kʌvɝd bɑksəz ɪn ðə kʌlɝz ə ði ədʒəz. wɛl, sɪks ə ði ədʒəz. baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən, ðə tu oʊldəst sɪɾɝz kəd kleɪm ðə pleɪsəz kloʊsəs tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit fəɹ ðɛɹ ədʒəz, soʊ jɛloʊ ən blu hɛl ðoʊz spɑts hɪɹ. æftɝ ðæt, ɪt wɑz ə mæɾɝ ə hu keɪm fɝst ən wɪʃt tə bi siɾəd wɛɹ, ðə fɝst ɝaɪvəl ɔlweɪz tʃuzɪŋ əɹ ədʒɑz pleɪs. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli naɪn sɪɾɝz pɹɛzənt, tu fju fəɹ ðə hɔl tə bi sɪɾɪŋ jɛt, liɡəli spikɪŋ, bʌɾ ən ɑɾəti ɪn ðə siɾɪŋ stʃɹʌk ɛɡwin ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ɹoʊmændə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn pleɪs, ən ɛmpti bɛntʃ bɪtwin əɹ ən sæliɾə, ən ləleɪn ən mɔɹiə ɑkjəpaɪd ði ɛn bɛntʃɪz ə ðə blu. ɹoʊmændə, hɝ hɛɹ ɪn ə taɪt ɡɹeɪ bʌn ɑn ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk, wɑz ði oʊldəst sɪɾɝ, ən ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ðə fɝs tə ɹitʃ əɹ pleɪs wən ðə hɔl sæt. ləleɪn, nɛkst oʊldəs dɪspaɪɾ əɹ dɑɹk ɡlɔsi hɛɹ, simd əneɪbəl tə lɛt ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɡeɪn ə dʒʌmp ɑn əɹ ivən ɪn sʌmθɪŋ soʊ smɔl. ðə mɛn u hæd ʃɪftəd ðə bɑksəz - ðeɪ wɝ stɔɹɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz əntɪl ðə hɔl wɑz kɔl tə sɪt - mʌst əv dʒʌs lɛf θɹu ðə bæk, kəz kweɪmɛsə, ɔlɹɛɾi siɾəd ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ, wɑz ði oʊnli ɡɹeɪ sɪɾɝ ɪn ɛvəɾəns, ən bɛɹænə, dʒʌs klaɪmɪŋ tə hɝz, ði oʊnli waɪt. bʌt mɑlɪnd, ə ɹaʊnd-feɪs kændɔɹi wɪð ən iɡəlz aɪz, ən ðə loʊn ɡɹin, ɑbviəsli hæɾ ɛntɝɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, jɛt stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən tə sit ðə ɡɹinz nɪɹ ðə pəvɪljənz ɛntʃɹɑns. ðə nɪɹɝ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit ðə bɛɾɝ, wɑz ðə juʒəwəl θɪŋ. ən dɝɛkli ɑpəzət hɝ, ɛskɹɑldi stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɹaʊn-kʌvɝd bɑksəz, ɪn hʌʃt ɑɹɡjəmənt wɪð tɑkimə. ɔlmoʊst əz ʃɔɹɾ əz naɪsaʊ, tɑkimə wɑz ə kwaɪət bɝd-laɪk wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kəd bi fɔɹsfəl wən ʃi wɪʃt, ən wɪð əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ʃi lʊkt ə spɛɹoʊ ɪn ə tɛmpɝ, fɛðɝz ɔl pʌft aʊt tə meɪk əɹ sim lɑɹdʒɝ. baɪ ðə weɪ ʃi kɛp dɑɹɾɪŋ ʃɑɹp lʊks təwɔɹd bɛɹænə, ðə siɾɪŋ wɑz wʌɾ əpsɛt hɝ. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə bi tʃeɪnʒd fəɹ ðɪs sɪɾɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɛskɹɑldi lum bæk ət tɑkimə əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə hæv tə faɪt fəɹ əɹ tʃɔɪs. ɪɾ əmeɪzd ɛɡwin haʊ ɛskɹɑldi kəd də ðæt. lum, ðət wɑz. ʃi stʊɾ ɪntʃəz ʃɔɹɾɝ ivən ðən naɪsaʊ. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn ʃɪɹ fɔɹs ʌv wɪl.

The arrangement of the pavilion followed ancient rules, modified only slightly to allow for the fact that they were not meeting in the White Tower, in the great circular chamber called the Hall of the Tower. At the far end, a simple if well polished bench stood atop a box-like platform covered with cloth striped in the seven colors of the Ajahs. That and the stole around Egwene's neck were surely the only places in the camp where the Red Ajah had any representation. Some Blues had wanted the color removed, since Elaida apparently had had the actual throne called the Amyrlin Seat repainted and a stole woven without blue, but Egwene had dug in her heels. If she was to be of all Ajahs and none, then she would be of all Ajahs. Down the bright layered carpets that served as a ground-cloth, two lines of benches slanted away from the entrance in groups of three, sitting atop cloth-covered boxes in the colors of the Ajahs. Well, six of the Ajahs. By tradition, the two oldest Sitters could claim the places closest to the Amyrlin Seat for their Ajahs, so Yellow and Blue held those spots here. After that, it was a matter of who came first and wished to be seated where, the first arrival always choosing her Ajah's place. There were only nine Sitters present, too few for the Hall to be sitting yet, legally speaking, but an oddity in the seating struck Egwene right away. Unsurprisingly, Romanda was already in place, an empty bench between her and Salita, and Lelaine and Moria occupied the end benches of the Blue. Romanda, her hair in a tight gray bun on the nape of her neck, was the oldest Sitter, and almost always the first to reach her place when the Hall sat. Lelaine, next oldest despite her dark glossy hair, seemed unable to let the other woman gain a jump on her even in something so small. The men who had shifted the boxes - they were stored along the walls until the Hall was called to sit - must have just left through the back, because Kwamesa, already seated on her bench, was the only Gray Sitter in evidence, and Berana, just climbing to hers, the only White. But Malind, a round-faced Kandori with an eagle's eyes, and the lone Green, obviously had entered ahead of them, yet strangely, she had chosen to seat the Greens near the pavilion's entrance. The nearer the Amyrlin Seat the better, was the usual thing. And directly opposite her, Escaralde stood in front of the brown-covered boxes, in hushed argument with Takima. Almost as short as Nisao, Takima was a quiet bird-like woman, but she could be forceful when she wished, and with her fists on her hips she looked a sparrow in a temper, feathers all puffed out to make her seem larger. By the way she kept darting sharp looks toward Berana, the seating was what upset her. It was too late for anything to be changed for this sitting, of course, but in any case, Escaralde loomed back at Takima as if she expected to have to fight for her choice. It amazed Egwene how Escaralde could do that. Loom, that was. She stood inches shorter even than Nisao. It must have been sheer force of will.

ɛskɹɑldi nɛvɝ bæk daʊn wən ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə ɹaɪt. ən ʃi ɔlweɪz dɪd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə ɹaɪt. ɪf mɔɹiə ɹɪli dɪd wɑn ən ɪmiɾiət əsɔlt ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən mɑlɪn ɹɪli wɑntəd tə ɹitʃɹit, wʌɾ ɛskɹɑldi wɑnt? fəɹ ɔl sɪuənz tɔk ə sɪɾɝz wɑntɪŋ tə bi wɔɹnd, ɛɡwinz ɛntʃɹəns kɑz noʊ ɡɹeɪt stɝ. fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɹizənz mɑlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz hæd kɔl ðə hɔl tə hɪɹ ækæɹənz ɹipɔɹt, ðeɪ hæd nɑt kənsɪɾɝd ðə mæɾɝ soʊ sɛnsəɾɪv ðəɾ ɪt niɾəd tə bi hɛl fəɹ sɪɾɝz' ɪɹz əloʊn, soʊ lɪɾəl klʌstɝz ə fɔɹ əɹ faɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə bɛntʃɪz ə ðɛɹ ədʒɑz sɪɾɝz, ən ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ kɝtsiz əz ɛɡwin wɔk daʊn ðə kɑɹpəts təwɔɹɾ əɹ oʊn sit. ðə sɪɾɝz ðɛmsɛlvz mɪɹli wɑtʃt hɝ, əɹ pɝhæps ɪnklaɪn ə hɛd bɹifli. ləleɪn aɪɾ əɹ kuli, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə fɹaʊnɪŋ feɪnli ət mɔɹiə, ə kwaɪɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi-əpɪɹɪŋ wʊmən ɪn pleɪn blu wʊl. soʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi, ɪn fækt, ðət jə kəd mɪs ði eɪdʒləs kwɑləɾi ɪn əɹ feɪs ət fɝst ɡlæns. ʃi sæt stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, əbzɔɹbd ɪn əɹ oʊn θɔts. ɹoʊmændə wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz tə tɪlt əɹ hɛɾ ə fɹækʃən.

Escaralde never backed down when she thought she was in the right. And she always did think she was in the right. If Moria really did want an immediate assault on Tar Valon, and Malind really wanted to retreat, what did Escaralde want? For all Siuan's talk of Sitters wanting to be warned, Egwene's entrance caused no great stir. For whatever reasons Malind and the others had called the Hall to hear Akarrin's report, they had not considered the matter so sensitive that it needed to be held for Sitters' ears alone, so little clusters of four or five Aes Sedai were standing behind the benches of their Ajah's Sitters, and they made their curtsies as Egwene walked down the carpets toward her own seat. The Sitters themselves merely watched her, or perhaps inclined a head briefly. Lelaine eyed her coolly, then returned to frowning faintly at Moria, a quite ordinary-appearing woman in plain blue wool. So ordinary, in fact, that you could miss the ageless quality in her face at first glance. She sat staring straight ahead, absorbed in her own thoughts. Romanda was one of those to tilt her head a fraction.

ɪnsaɪd ðə hɔl, ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɑz stɪl ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, bʌɾ ə lɪɾəl lɛs soʊ ðən aʊtsaɪɾ ɪt. ɪnsaɪd ðə hɔl, sɪɾɝz fɛl ðɛɹ paʊɝ. ɪn ə weɪ, ði æmɪɝlɪn kəd bi sɛd tə bi oʊnli ðə fɝst əmʌŋ ikwəlz, ɪnsaɪd ðə hɔl. wɛl, pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ðæt, bʌt nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ. sɪuən sɛɾ əz mɛni æmɪɝlənz hæd feɪl baɪ bɪlivɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ fʊli hɝ ikwəlz əz baɪ bɪlivɪŋ ðə dɪfɝəns wɑz waɪɾɝ ðən ɹɪli ɪɡzɪstəd. ɪt wɑz laɪk ɹʌnɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə tɑp ʌv ə nɛɹoʊ wɔl wɪð fɪɹs mæstəfs ɑn iðɝ saɪd. jə meɪnteɪn ə kɛɹfəl bæləns ən tʃɹaɪd tə wɑtʃ jəɹ fit mɔɹ ðən ðə dɑɡz. bʌt jə wɝ ɔlweɪz əwɛɹ ə ðə dɑɡz. ənpɪnɪŋ əɹ kloʊk əz ʃi stɛpt ʌp ɑntu ðə stʃɹaɪp bɑks, ɛɡwin foʊldəɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ bɛntʃ bɪfɔɹ sɪɾɪŋ. ðə bɛntʃɪz wɝ hɑɹd, ən səm sɪɾɝz bɹɔt kʊʃənz wən ðeɪ θɔt ðə sɪɾɪŋ wəd bi lɔŋ. ɛɡwin pɹəfɝd nɑt tə. ðə pɹoʊəbɪʃən ɑn spitʃəz sɛldəm stɑpt ət list wʌn əɹ tu wɪmən fɹəm dʒɹɔɪŋ ðɛɹ kɑmɛns aʊɾ ət lɛŋθ, ən ə hɑɹd sit kəd hɛlp jə ɹɪmeɪn əweɪk θɹu ðə wɝst. ʃɛɹiəm tʊk ðə kipɝz pleɪs stændɪŋ tə ɛɡwinz lɛft, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt weɪt. meɪbi ʃi ʃʊɾə bɹɔɾ ə kʊʃən.

Inside the Hall, the Amyrlin Seat was still the Amyrlin Seat, but a little less so than outside it. Inside the Hall, Sitters felt their power. In a way, the Amyrlin could be said to be only the first among equals, inside the Hall. Well, perhaps a little more than that, but not by much. Siuan said as many Amyrlins had failed by believing the Sitters were fully her equals as by believing the difference was wider than really existed. It was like running along the top of a narrow wall with fierce mastiffs on either side. You maintained a careful balance and tried to watch your feet more than the dogs. But you were always aware of the dogs. Unpinning her cloak as she stepped up onto the striped box, Egwene folded it across her bench before sitting. The benches were hard, and some Sitters brought cushions when they thought the sitting would be long. Egwene preferred not to. The prohibition on speeches seldom stopped at least one or two women from drawing their comments out at length, and a hard seat could help you remain awake through the worst. Sheriam took the Keeper's place standing to Egwene's left, and there was nothing to do but wait. Maybe she should have brought a cushion.

ði ʌðɝ bɛntʃɪz wɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fɪl, ðoʊ sloʊli. ələdʒɹɪn ən sɛɝɔɪjə hæd dʒɔɪn bɛɹænə, ələdʒɹɪn plʌmp ɪnʌf tə meɪk ði ʌðɝ tu əpɪɹ slɪm. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə vɝɾɪkəl laɪnz ʌv waɪt skɹɑlwɝk ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn sɛɝɔɪjəz skɝts hæd ðəɾ ɪfɛkt ɛniweɪ, waɪl ələdʒɹɪnz waɪd waɪt slivz ən ðə snoʊi pænəl ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ dʒɹɛs dɪd dʒʌs ði ɑpəzət. itʃ əpɛɹənli wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ði ʌðɝz nu wʌt wɑz əfʊt, fɹəm ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ən ʃuɾɪŋ ɡlænsɪz təwɔɹd ðə bluz, ðə bɹaʊnz ən ðə ɡɹinz. vɛɹɪlɪn, ə ɹɛd-hɛɹd stɔɹk ʌv ə wʊmən ən tɔlɝ ðən moʊs mɛn, hæd teɪkən əɹ sit bɪsaɪd kweɪmɛsə, tu. ədʒʌstɪŋ ən ɹiədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl ɹɛsləsli, vɛɹɪlɪn dɑɹɾɪd əɹ aɪz fɹəm mɔɹiə tə ɛskɹɑldi tə mɑlɪn ən bæk.

The other benches were beginning to fill, though slowly. Aledrin and Saroiya had joined Berana, Aledrin plump enough to make the other two appear slim. Of course, the vertical lines of white scrollwork running down Saroiya's skirts had that effect anyway, while Aledrin's wide white sleeves and the snowy panel running down the front of her dress did just the opposite. Each apparently was trying to find out whether the others knew what was afoot, from the way they were shaking their heads at each other and shooting glances toward the Blues, the Browns and the Greens. Varilin, a red-haired stork of a woman and taller than most men, had taken her seat beside Kwamesa, too. Adjusting and readjusting her shawl restlessly, Varilin darted her eyes from Moria to Escaralde to Malind and back.

mæɡlə, jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɹæp taɪtli ɝaʊn əɹ bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz, ən feɪsɛl, ə skwɹəfeɪs dəmɑni ɪn sɪlks kʌvɝd wɪð dɛns ɡɹin ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, wɝ dʒʌst ɛntɝɪŋ ðə pəvɪljən, itʃ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝ ivən wən ðɛɹ skɝts bɹʌʃt. mæɡlə wɑz fɝmli ɪn ɹoʊmændəz kæmp ən feɪsɛl ɪn ləleɪnz, ən ðə tu ɡɹups dɪd nɑt mɪks. ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɝ tʃɹɪklɪŋ ɪn baɪ spɝts, əz wɛl, naɪsaʊ ən maɪɹɛl əmʌŋ hæf ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ hu slɪpt ɪn bɪhaɪn mæɡlə ən feɪsɛl. mɔɹvɹɪn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi əmʌŋ ðə bɹaʊnz bɪhaɪn tɑkimə ən ɛskɹɑldi, ən bioʊnɪn stʊɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹeɪz bɪhaɪn vɛɹɪlɪn ən kweɪmɛsə. ət ðɪs ɹeɪt, hæf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə kæmp wəd bi kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ.

Magla, yellow-fringed shawl wrapped tightly around her broad shoulders, and Faiselle, a squarefaced Domani in silks covered with dense green embroidery, were just entering the pavilion, each ignoring the other even when their skirts brushed. Magla was firmly in Romanda's camp and Faiselle in Lelaine's, and the two groups did not mix. Other sisters were trickling in by spurts, as well, Nisao and Myrelle among half a dozen or so who slipped in behind Magla and Faiselle. Morvrin was already among the Browns behind Takima and Escaralde, and Beonin stood on the edge of the Grays behind Varilin and Kwamesa. At this rate, half the Aes Sedai in the camp would be crowded into the pavilion before long.

waɪl mæɡlə wɑz stɪl wɔkɪŋ daʊn ðə kɑɹpəts təwɔɹd ðə jɛloʊ sits, ɹoʊmændə ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit. "wi ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɪlɛvən naʊ, soʊ wi meɪ əz wɛl bɪɡɪn." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli haɪpɪtʃt.

While Magla was still walking down the carpets toward the Yellow seats, Romanda rose to her feet. "We are more than eleven now, so we may as well begin." Her voice was surprisingly highpitched.

jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ʃi hæɾ ə bjuɾəfəl sɪŋɪŋ vɔɪs, ɪf jə kəɾ ɪmædʒən ɹoʊmændə sɪŋɪŋ. hɝ feɪs ɔlweɪz simd mɔɹ sɛt fəɹ skoʊldɪŋ, ət list slaɪtli dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi nid meɪk ðɪs ə fɔɹməl sɛʃən," ʃi æɾəd wən kweɪmɛsə stʊd. "aɪ hɑɹdli si waɪ ðɪs nid bi dʌn ɪn sɛʃən əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ ɪf ɪt mʌst, lɛɾ əs ɡɛɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ən aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. səm ʌv əs əv mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz tə dil wɪð. əz aɪm ʃʊɹ jə du, mʌðɝ."

You might have thought she had a beautiful singing voice, if you could imagine Romanda singing. Her face always seemed more set for scolding, at least slightly disapproving. "I don't think we need make this a formal session," she added when Kwamesa stood. "I hardly see why this need be done in session at all, but if it must, let us get it over and out of the way. Some of us have more important matters to deal with. As I'm sure you do, Mother."

ðət læst wɑz sɛd wɪð ə dip baʊ ʌv əɹ hɛd, ɪn ə toʊn pɝhæps ə hɛɹ tu ɹɪspɛkfəl. nɑt fɑɹ ɪnʌf oʊvɝ ðə laɪn tə bi kɔl sɑɹkæzəm, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wɑz tu ɪntɛlədʒən tə pleɪs hɝsɛlf ɪn dʒɛpɝɾi; fulz sɛldəm əteɪn ə sɪɾɝz tʃɛɹ, əɹ hɛld ɪt lɔŋ, ən ɹoʊmændə hæd hɛld ə siɾ ɪn ðə hɔl fəɹ ɔlmoʊst eɪɾi jɪɹz. ðɪs wɑz əɹ sɛkən taɪm əz ə sɪɾɝ. ɛɡwin ɪnklaɪn əɹ oʊn hɛd slaɪtli, aɪz kul. ən æknɑlɪdʒmən ðət ʃi hæd bɪn ədʒɹɛst ən ðət ʃi hæd mɑɹk ðə toʊn. ə vɛɹi kɛɹfəl bæləns.

That last was said with a deep bow of her head, in a tone perhaps a hair too respectful. Not far enough over the line to be called sarcasm, of course. She was too intelligent to place herself in jeopardy; fools seldom attained a Sitter's chair, or held it long, and Romanda had held a seat in the Hall for almost eighty years. This was her second time as a Sitter. Egwene inclined her own head slightly, eyes cool. An acknowledgment that she had been addressed and that she had marked the tone. A very careful balance.

kweɪmɛsə wɑz lɛf lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð əɹ maʊθ oʊpən, ənsɝɾən wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz tə spik ðə fɹeɪzəz, ɔlweɪz ʌɾɝd baɪ ðə jʌŋɡəst sɪɾɝ pɹɛzənt, ðəɾ oʊpən ə fɔɹməl sɪɾɪŋ ə ðə hɔl. ɹoʊmændəz pleɪs ɡeɪv əɹ kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɪnfluəns ən səm mɛʒɝ ʌv əθɔɹəɾi, jɛɾ ʌðɝz kəɾ oʊvɝɹaɪɾ əɹ ɪn ðɪs. ə nʌmbɝ ə sɪɾɝz fɹaʊn əɹ ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðɛɹ bɛntʃɪz, bʌt noʊ wʌn spoʊk. laɪɹɛl ɡlaɪɾɪd ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən, ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹd ðə blu bɛntʃɪz. tɔl fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn wʊmən, wɪtʃ meɪɾ əɹ ʌv ævɝɪdʒ haɪt fəɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, ʃi wɑz ɛləɡən ɪn blu-slæʃt sɪlk ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə bɑɾəs wɪð ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld, hɝ muvməns floʊɪŋ. səm sɛd ʃi hæd bɪn ə dænsɝ bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ əz ə nɑvəs. baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən, səmeɪlɪn, ðə fɑks-feɪst ɡɹin u ɛntɝɾ ɑn əɹ hilz, sim tə stʃɹaɪd mænɪʃli, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl ɑkwɝɾ əbaʊt ðə mʊɹændiən wʊmən. ðeɪ boʊθ sim sɝpɹaɪz tə si kweɪmɛsə ɑn əɹ fit, ən hɝid tə ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛktɪv bɛntʃɪz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, vɛɹɪlɪn bɪɡæn plʌkɪŋ ət kweɪmɛsəz sliv, əntɪl ði ɝæfɛlɪn wʊmən faɪnəli sæt daʊn. kweɪmɛsəz feɪs wɑz ə mæsk ə kul kɑmnəs, jɛt ʃi mænədʒ tə ɹeɪɾiət dɪsplɛʒɝ. ʃi pʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪt stɔɹ ɪn sɛɹəmoʊni. "pɝhæps ðəɹ ɪz ɹizən fəɹ fɔɹməl sɛʃən." ləleɪnz vɔɪs sim loʊ, æftɝ ɹoʊmændəz. ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə wɝld, ʃi ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli, vɛɹi dɪlɪbɝətli nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin. ə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən, ləleɪn stɪl wɑz dɪɡnəɾi ɪnkɑɹnət. "ɪt simz ðət tɔks wɪð ɪleɪɾə hæv bɪn laɪsənst," ʃi sɛd kuli. "aɪ də ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ʌndɝ ðə lɔ ʌv wɔɹ, wi nid nɑt bi kənsʌltəɾ ɑn ðɪs, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlsoʊ bɪliv wi ʃəd dɪskʌs ɪɾ ɪn sɛʃən, ɪspɛʃli sɪns mɛni ʌv əs feɪs ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv biɪŋ stɪld ɪf ɪleɪɾə ɹɪteɪnz ɛni paʊɝ."

Kwamesa was left looking around with her mouth open, uncertain whether she was to speak the phrases, always uttered by the youngest Sitter present, that opened a formal sitting of the Hall. Romanda's place gave her considerable influence and some measure of authority, yet others could override her in this. A number of Sitters frowned or shifted on their benches, but no one spoke. Lyrelle glided into the pavilion, glided toward the Blue benches. Tall for a Cairhienin woman, which made her of average height for almost anywhere else, she was elegant in blue-slashed silk embroidered on the bodice with red and gold, her movements flowing. Some said she had been a dancer before coming to the Tower as a novice. By comparison, Samalin, the fox-faced Green who entered on her heels, seemed to stride mannishly, though there was nothing at all awkward about the Murandian woman. They both seemed surprised to see Kwamesa on her feet, and hurried to their respective benches. In any case, Varilin began plucking at Kwamesa's sleeve, until the Arafellin woman finally sat down. Kwamesa's face was a mask of cool calmness, yet she managed to radiate displeasure. She put a great store in ceremony. "Perhaps there is reason for formal session." Lelaine's voice seemed low, after Romanda's. Arranging her shawl as though she had all the time in the world, she rose gracefully, very deliberately not looking at Egwene. A beautiful woman, Lelaine still was dignity incarnate. "It seems that talks with Elaida have been licensed," she said coolly. "I do understand that under the Law of War, we need not be consulted on this, but I also believe we should discuss it in session, especially since many of us face the possibility of being stilled if Elaida retains any power."

ðət wɝd, "stɪld," noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kæɹid kwaɪt ðə tʃɪl ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ sɪuən ən lin wɝ hil fɹəm stɪlɪŋ, bʌt mɝmɝz ɹoʊz əmʌŋ ðə wɑtʃɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɹaʊɾəd bɪhaɪn ðə bɛntʃɪz. ɪt sim ðət nuz ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz hæd nɑt spɹɛɾ əz kwɪkli əz ɛɡwin ɪkspɛktəd. ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl wɛðɝ ðə sɪstɝz wɝ ɪksaɪɾəd əɹ dɪsmeɪd, bʌt klɪɹli ðeɪ wɝ sɝpɹaɪzd. ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm ə ðə sɪɾɝz. dʒɑnjə, hu hæɾ ɛntɝd waɪl ləleɪn wɑz spikɪŋ, stɑp dɛɾ ɪn əɹ tʃɹæks, soʊ ðəɾ ənʌðɝ nɑɾ ə sɪstɝz kʌmɪŋ ɪn nɪɹli wɔkt ɪndə hɝ. ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə blu, ðən lɔŋɡɝ ən hɑɹɾɝ əɾ ɛɡwin hɝsɛlf.

That word, "stilled," no longer carried quite the chill it had before Siuan and Leane were Healed from stilling, but murmurs rose among the watching Aes Sedai crowded behind the benches. It seemed that news of negotiations had not spread as quickly as Egwene expected. She could not tell whether the sisters were excited or dismayed, but clearly they were surprised. Including some of the Sitters. Janya, who had entered while Lelaine was speaking, stopped dead in her tracks, so that another knot of sisters coming in nearly walked into her. She stared at the Blue, then longer and harder at Egwene herself.

ɹoʊmændə pleɪnli hæd nɑt hɝɾ iðɝ, fɹəm ðə weɪ hɝ maʊθ hɑɹɾənd, ən ɪkspɹɛʃənz əmʌŋ ðə tu-jʌŋ sɪɾɝz ɹeɪnʒd fɹəm bɛɹænəz aɪsi kɑm tə əmeɪzd ɑn səmeɪlɪnz pɑɹɾ ən oʊpənli əpɔld ɑn sæliɾəz. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃɛɹiəm sweɪɾ ɑn əɹ fit fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ɛɡwin hoʊp ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt sɪk ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪntaɪɝ hɔl. mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, ðoʊ, wɝ ðə ɹiækʃənz ə ðoʊz dɛlænə hæd ɹipɔɹɾəd əz spikɪŋ ə nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən. vɛɹɪlɪn sæt vɛɹi stɪl ən sim tə bi səpɹɛsɪŋ ə smaɪl əz ʃi stʌɾid əɹ skɝts, bʌt mæɡlə lɪkt əɹ lɪps hɛzɪɾəntli ən kæst ɡlænsɪz ət ɹoʊmændə fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. sɛɝɔɪjə hæɾ əɹ aɪz kloʊzd, ən əɹ maʊθ muvd əz ðoʊ ʃi maɪt bi ʌɾɝɪŋ ə pɹɛɹ.

Romanda plainly had not heard either, from the way her mouth hardened, and expressions among the too-young Sitters ranged from Berana's icy calm to amazed on Samalin's part and openly appalled on Salita's. For that matter, Sheriam swayed on her feet for a moment. Egwene hoped the woman would not sick up in front of the entire Hall. More interesting, though, were the reactions of those Delana had reported as speaking of negotiation. Varilin sat very still and seemed to be suppressing a smile as she studied her skirts, but Magla licked her lips hesitantly and cast glances at Romanda from the corner of her eye. Saroiya had her eyes closed, and her mouth moved as though she might be uttering a prayer.

feɪsɛl ən tɑkimə ɡeɪzd əɾ ɛɡwin wɛɹɪŋ ɔlmoʊst aɪdɛntɪkəl taɪni fɹaʊnz. ðən itʃ noʊɾəst ði ʌðɝ ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, kwɪkli əsumɪŋ sətʃ ɹiɡəl sɝɛnəɾi ðət ðeɪ sim tə bi mɑkɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ. ʃʊɹli baɪ naʊ bioʊnɪn hæɾ ɪnfɔɹmd ɔl ə ðɛm wʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd sɛd, jɛɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ vɛɹɪlɪn, ðeɪ simd ʌpsɛt. ðeɪ kəd nɑt pɑsəbli hæv θɔt ðeɪ maɪt ɹɪli nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ən ɛnd.

Faiselle and Takima gazed at Egwene wearing almost identical tiny frowns. Then each noticed the other and gave a start, quickly assuming such regal serenity that they seemed to be mocking one another. It was very strange. Surely by now Beonin had informed all of them what Egwene had said, yet except for Varilin, they seemed upset. They could not possibly have thought they might really negotiate an end.

ɛvɹi wʊmən sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɪs hɔl ɹɪsk stɪlɪŋ ən ɛksəkjuʃən dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ ðɛɹ. ɪf ðəɹ ɛvɝ hæd bɪn ɛni pæθ bæk ɪksɛp tə ɹimuv ɪleɪɾə, ɪt hæd wɑʃt əweɪ mʌnθs əɡoʊ, wən ðɪs hɔl wɑz tʃoʊzən.

Every woman sitting in this Hall risked stilling and execution just by being there. If there ever had been any path back except to remove Elaida, it had washed away months ago, when this Hall was chosen.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk fɹəm ðæt. ləleɪn əpɪɹd sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ðə ɹiækʃənz tə hɝ wɝdz - smʌɡ əz ə kæɾ ɪn ðə mɪlkbɑɹn, ɪn fækt - bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɪnɪʃt sɛɾəlɪŋ bæk ɑntu hɝ bɛntʃ, mɔɹiə baʊndəd tə hɝ fit. ðət kɑɾ ɛvɹi aɪ ən kɑzd ə fju mɔɹ mɝmɝz. noʊ wʌn kɔl mɔɹiə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɡɹeɪsfəl, bʌt ði ɪliɑnɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən u baʊndəd. "ðæt də nid dɪskʌʃən," ʃi sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪt mʌs kʌm leɪɾɝ. ðɪs hɔl dɪd bi kɔl baɪ θɹi sɪɾɝz æskɪŋ ðə seɪm kwɛstʃən. ðət kwɛstʃən mʌs bi ədʒɹɛs bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ. wʌɾ ækæɹən ən əɹ pɑɹɾi faɪnd? aɪ də æsk ðeɪ bi bɹɔɾ ɪn tə meɪk ðɛɹ ɹipɔɹt bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl."

There was no going back from that. Lelaine appeared satisfied with the reactions to her words - smug as a cat in the milkbarn, in fact - but before she finished settling back onto her bench, Moria bounded to her feet. That caught every eye and caused a few more murmurs. No one called Moria particularly graceful, but the Illianer was not a woman who bounded. "That do need discussion," she said, "but it must come later. This Hall did be called by three Sitters asking the same question. That question must be addressed before any other. What did Akarrin and her party find? I do ask they be brought in to make their report before the Hall."

ləleɪn skaʊld əɾ əɹ fɛloʊ blu, ən ʃi kəd skaʊl wɪð ðə bɛst, hɝ aɪz əz ʃɑɹp əz ɔlz, jɛt taʊɝ lɔ wɑz kwaɪt pleɪn ɑn ðə sʌbʒɪkt, fəɹ wʌns, ən wɛl noʊn tə ɛvɹiwʌn. ɔfən ɪnʌf, ɪt wɑz niðɝ. ɪn ən ənstɛɾi vɔɪs, ʃɛɹiəm æskt ələdʒɹɪn, ðə jʌŋɡəst æftɝ kweɪmɛsə, tə ɡoʊ ən ɛskɔɹɾ ækæɹən ən ði ʌðɝz bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl. ɛɡwin dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃi hæd bɛs tɔk tə ðə faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən əz sun əz ðɪs sɪɾɪŋ wɑz dʌn. ɪf ʃɛɹiəm kɛpt ɑn ðɪs weɪ, ʃi wəd sun bɪkʌm wɝs ðən jusləs əz kipɝ. dɛlænə dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə pəvɪljən əmɪɾ ə klʌstɝ ə sɪstɝz, ðə læst sɪɾɝ tə ɝaɪv, ən wɑz ɑn əɹ bɛntʃ dʒɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl əkɹɔs əɹ ɛlboʊz baɪ ðə taɪm ðə plʌmp waɪt sɪɾɝ ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ðə sɪks sɪstɝz ən lɛɾ əm tə stæn bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin. ðeɪ mʌst əv lɛf ðɛɹ kloʊks ɑn ðə wɔkweɪ aʊtsaɪd, kəz nʌn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ wʌn naʊ. dɛlænə pɪɹɾ ət ðɛm, ən ənsɝɾən fɹaʊn dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ aɪbɹaʊz daʊn. ʃi simd aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɹʌn tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ.

Lelaine scowled at her fellow Blue, and she could scowl with the best, her eyes as sharp as awls, yet Tower law was quite plain on the subject, for once, and well known to everyone. Often enough, it was neither. In an unsteady voice, Sheriam asked Aledrin, the youngest after Kwamesa, to go and escort Akarrin and the others before the Hall. Egwene decided she had best talk to the fire-haired woman as soon as this sitting was done. If Sheriam kept on this way, she would soon become worse than useless as Keeper. Delana darted into the pavilion amid a cluster of sisters, the last Sitter to arrive, and was on her bench draping her shawl across her elbows by the time the plump White Sitter returned with the six sisters and led them to stand before Egwene. They must have left their cloaks on the walkway outside, because none was wearing one now. Delana peered at them, an uncertain frown drawing her eyebrows down. She seemed out of breath, as though she had run to get there.

əpɛɹənli, ələdʒɹɪn fɛl ðət wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðə sɪɾɪŋ wɑz fɔɹməl, ʃi, ət list, ʃəd kæɹi ɑn wɪð pɹɑpɝ fɔɹmæləɾi. "ju hæv bɪn kɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ tə ɹɪleɪt wʌt juv sin," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛnt. hɝ kɑmbəneɪʃən ə dɑɹk ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ən bɹaʊn aɪz wɑz nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl ɪn tæɹɑbən, ðoʊ ʃi wɔɹ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ hɛɹ kɑɾ ɪn ə leɪsi waɪt nɛt ɹæðɝ ðən ɪn biɾɪd bɹeɪdz. "aɪ tʃɑɹdʒ jə tə spik ə ðiz θɪŋz wɪθaʊt ði ɪveɪʒən əɹ hoʊldɪŋ bæk, ən tə ænsɝ ɔl kwɛstʃənz ɪn kəmplit fʊlnəs, livɪŋ aʊt nʌθɪŋ. seɪ naʊ ðət jəl də soʊ, ʌndɝ ðə laɪɾ ən baɪ jəɹ hoʊp ə ðə ɹibɝθ ən sælveɪʃən, əɹ sʌfɝ ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz." ðoʊz eɪntʃən sɪstɝz u meɪd ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə hɔlz sɛɹəmoʊni hæd bɪn wɛl əwɛɹ ə haʊ mʌtʃ liweɪ ðə θɹi oʊðz ɡeɪv. ə lɪɾəl lɛft aʊt hɪɹ, ə tʌtʃ ə veɪɡnɪs ðɛɹ, ən ðə hoʊl minɪŋ ʌv wʌt jə sɛd kəd bi stʊɾ ɑn ɪts hɛd, ɔl waɪl jə spoʊk oʊnli ðə tʃɹuθ. ækæɹən spoʊk ði əʃʊɹəns laʊdli ən sʌmwʌɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli, ði ʌðɝ faɪv wɪð vɛɹiɪŋ lɛvəlz ə fɔɹmæləɾi ən sɛlfkɑnʃəsnəs. mɛni sɪstɝz hæd lɪv ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝ lɪvz wɪθaʊt biɪŋ kɔl tə tɛstəfaɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə hɔl. ələdʒɹɪn weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə læs hæd ɹɪpiɾɪd ɛvɹi wɝd bɪfɔɹ mɑɹtʃɪŋ bæk təwɔɹɾ əɹ bɛntʃ. "tɛl əs wʌt jə dɪd si, ækæɹən," mɔɹiə sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə waɪt sɪɾɝ tɝn əweɪ. ələdʒɹɪn stɪfən vɪzəbli, ən wən ʃi tʊk əɹ sit, hɝ feɪs wɑz ʌɾɝli ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, bʌt bɹaɪt spɑts ə kʌlɝ haɪlaɪɾɪd əɹ tʃiks. mɔɹiə ʃəɾ əv weɪɾəd. ʃi mʌst əv bɪn vɛɹi æŋkʃəs.

Apparently, Aledrin felt that whether or not the sitting was formal, she, at least, should carry on with proper formality. "You have been called before the Hall of the Tower to relate what you have seen," she said in a strong Taraboner accent. Her combination of dark golden hair and brown eyes was not unusual in Tarabon, though she wore her shoulder-length hair caught in a lacy white net rather than in beaded braids. "I charge you to speak of these things without the evasion or holding back, and to answer all questions in complete fullness, leaving out nothing. Say now that you will do so, under the Light and by your hope of the rebirth and salvation, or suffer the consequences." Those ancient sisters who made this part of the Hall's ceremony had been well aware of how much leeway the Three Oaths gave. A little left out here, a touch of vagueness there, and the whole meaning of what you said could be stood on its head, all while you spoke only the truth. Akarrin spoke the assurance loudly and somewhat impatiently, the other five with varying levels of formality and selfconsciousness. Many sisters had lived their entire lives without being called to testify in front of the Hall. Aledrin waited until the last had repeated every word before marching back toward her bench. "Tell us what you did see, Akarrin," Moria said as soon as the White Sitter turned away. Aledrin stiffened visibly, and when she took her seat, her face was utterly expressionless, but bright spots of color highlighted her cheeks. Moria should have waited. She must have been very anxious.

baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən - ðəɹ wɝ mɛni mɔɹ tʃɹədɪʃənz ən kʌstəmz ðən lɔz, ən ðə laɪt nu ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ lɔz ðən ɛniwʌn ɹɪli nu, ɔfən kɑntʃɹədɪktɝi leɪɝz ə lɔ leɪd daʊn oʊvɝ ðə sɛntʃɝiz, bʌt tʃɹədɪʃən ən kʌstəm ɹuld ɛɛs sədaɪ əz mʌtʃ əz taʊɝ lɔ ɛvɝ hæd, pɝhæps mɔɹ soʊ - baɪ tʃɹədɪʃən, ækæɹən ədʒɹɛst əɹ ɹɪspɑns tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

By tradition - there were many more traditions and customs than laws, and the Light knew there were more laws than anyone really knew, often contradictory layers of law laid down over the centuries, but tradition and custom ruled Aes Sedai as much as Tower law ever had, perhaps more so - by tradition, Akarrin addressed her response to the Amyrlin Seat.

"wʌt wi sɔ, mʌðɝ, wɑz ə ɹʌfli sɝkjəlɝ hoʊl ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd," ʃi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛmfəsəs ət nɪɹli ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wɝd. ʃi sim tə tʃuz ðoʊz wɝdz kɛɹfəli, əz ɪf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz æbsəlutli klɪɹ tə ɛvɹiwʌn. "ɪt meɪ hæv bɪn ə pɹɪsaɪs sɝkəl, ɝɪdʒənəli, ʃeɪp laɪk hæf ʌv ə bɔl, bʌt ðə saɪdz əv kəlæpst ɪn səm pleɪsəz. ðə hoʊl ɪz əpɹɑksəmətli θɹi maɪlz əkɹɔs ən pɝhæps ə maɪl ən ə hæf dip." sʌmwʌn ɡæsp laʊdli, ən ækæɹən fɹaʊn əz ðoʊ huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪntɝʌpt. ʃi wɛn ɑn wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ. "wi kəd nɑt bi ɪntaɪɝli sɝɾən ə ðə dɛpθ. ðə bɑɾəm ɪz kʌvɝd wɪð wɔɾɝ ən aɪs. wi bɪliv ɪt meɪ bɪkʌm ə leɪk, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, wi wɝ eɪbəl tə æsɝteɪn əɹ ɪɡzæk loʊkeɪʃən wɪθaʊt tu mʌtʃ dɪfəkəlti, ən wəɹ pɹipɛɹd tə seɪ ðət ðə hoʊl ɪz loʊkeɪɾəd wɛɹ ðə sɪɾi kɔld ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wʌns stʊd." ʃi fɛl saɪlənt, ən fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ði oʊnli saʊnd wɑz ðə ɹʌsəl ə skɝts əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli.

"What we saw, Mother, was a roughly circular hole in the ground," she said, nodding for emphasis at nearly every other word. She seemed to choose those words carefully, as if to make sure she was absolutely clear to everyone. "It may have been a precise circle, originally, shaped like half of a ball, but the sides have collapsed in some places. The hole is approximately three miles across and perhaps a mile and a half deep." Someone gasped loudly, and Akarrin frowned as though whoever it was had tried to interrupt. She went on without pausing, however. "We could not be entirely certain of the depth. The bottom is covered with water and ice. We believe it may become a lake, eventually. In any event, we were able to ascertain our exact location without too much difficulty, and we are prepared to say that the hole is located where the city called Shadar Logoth once stood." She fell silent, and for a long moment the only sound was the rustle of skirts as Aes Sedai shifted uneasily.

ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə ʃɪft, tu. laɪt, ə hoʊl ðət saɪz wəd kʌvɝ hæf ə tɑɹ vəlɑn! "du juv ɛni aɪdiə haʊ ðɪs . . . hoʊl . . . wɑz kɹieɪɾəd, ækæɹən?" ʃi æsk faɪnəli. ʃi wɑz kwaɪt pɹaʊɾ ə haʊ stɛɾi hɝ vɔɪs wɑz. ʃɛɹiəm wɑz æktʃəli  tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ! ɛɡwin hoʊp noʊ wʌn ɛls noʊɾəst. eɪ kipɝz ækʃənz ɔlweɪz ɹəflɛktəɾ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɪf ðə kipɝ ʃoʊd fɪɹ, ə ɡʊd mɛni sɪstɝz wəd θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz əfɹeɪd. ðət wɑz hɑɹdli sʌmθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəɾ ɛniwʌn tə səspɛkt.

Egwene wanted to shift, too. Light, a hole that size would cover half of Tar Valon! "Do you have any idea how this . . . hole . . . was created, Akarrin?" she asked finally. She was quite proud of how steady her voice was. Sheriam was actually trembling! Egwene hoped no one else noticed. A Keeper's actions always reflected on the Amyrlin. If the Keeper showed fear, a good many sisters would think that Egwene was afraid. That was hardly something she wanted anyone to suspect.

"itʃ ʌv əs wɑz tʃoʊzən kəz wɪv səm əbɪləɾi ət ɹiɾɪŋ ɹɛzəduz, mʌðɝ. bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst, ɪn tʃɹuθ." soʊ ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn tʃoʊzən sɪmpli kəz noʊ wʌn stʃɹɔŋɝ wɑz ɪntʃɹəstəd. ðəɹ wɑz ə lɛsən ɪn ðæt. wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd wɑz sɛldəm əz sɪmpəl əz ɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə sɝfəs. ɛɡwin wɪʃt ʃi kəd stɑp hævɪŋ tə ɹilɝn lɛsənz ʃi hæd θɔɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɝnd. "naɪsən ɪz ðə bɛst ʌv əs ət ðæt," ækæɹən wɛn ɑn. "wɪð jəɹ pɝmɪʃən, mʌðɝ, əl lɛɾ əɹ ænsɝ." naɪsən smuðd əɹ dɑɹk wʊlən skɝts nɝvəsli ən klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. ə ɡæŋli ɡɹeɪ wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ tʃɪn ən stɑɹtlɪŋli blu aɪz, ʃi hæd səm smɔl ɹipjuɾ ɪn mæɾɝz ə lɔ ən tʃɹiɾiz, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɑbviəsli ənizi əbaʊt spikɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl. ʃi lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ ɛɡwin wɪð ði ɛɹ ə sʌmwʌn u dɪd nɑt wɑnə æktʃəli  si ɔl ðə sɪɾɝz əsɛmbəld. "ɡɪvən ði əmaʊn ə seɪaɪdɑɹ juz ðɛɹ, mʌðɝ, ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðə ɹɛzəduz nɪɹ əz θɪk əz ðə snoʊ." mɔɹ ðən ə hɪn ə mʊɹændi klʌŋ tə hɝ tʌŋ, ə lɪltɪŋ saʊnd. "ivən æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ, ʃʊɾə əv bɪn eɪbəl tə ɡɹæsp səm aɪdiə ʌv wʌt wɑz woʊvən, ɪf ɪt wɑz əɾ ɔl laɪk ɛniθɪŋ aɪm fəmɪljɝ wɪð, bʌɾ aɪ hæv nʌn. aɪ kəɾ ɔl bʌt tʃɹeɪs ðə wiv, mʌðɝ, ən ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl. nʌn. ɪn fækt, ɪt sim soʊ eɪliən, ɪt maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn. . . . " klɪɹɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn, ʃi swɑloʊd. hɝ feɪs ɡɹu ə lɪɾəl pəlɝ. "ɪt maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn woʊvən baɪ ə wʊmən. wi θɔɾ ɪt mʌst əv bɪn ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ʌv kɔɹs, soʊ aɪ tɛstəd fəɹ ɹɛzənəns. wi ɔl dɪd." hæftɝnɪŋ tə dʒɛstʃɝ tə hɝ kəmpænjənz, ʃi hɝidli tɝn bæk. ʃi dɛfənətli pɹəfɝd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛɡwin tə ðə sɪɾɝz, ɔl linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli. "aɪ kæn seɪ wʌt wɑz dʌn, bɪɑn skupɪŋ θɹi maɪlz aʊɾ ə ði ɝθ, əɹ haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn, bʌt seɪɾɪn wɑz dɛfənətli juzd, tu. ðə ɹɛzənəns wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ, ʃʊɾə əv bɪn eɪbəl tə smɛl ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ seɪɾɪn juz ðən seɪaɪdɑɹ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ, dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn bɪsaɪɾ ə fʊthɪl. ən ðəɾ ɪz ɔl aɪ kən seɪ, mʌðɝ." ə saʊn flʌɾɝd θɹu ðə pəvɪljən, ðə saʊn ə sɪstɝz lɛɾɪŋ aʊt ðə bɹɛθ ðeɪ hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ. ʃɛɹiəmz ɛkshəleɪʃən sim ðə laʊɾəst, bʌt pɝhæps ðət wɑz dʒʌs kəz ʃi wɑz nɪɹəst.

"Each of us was chosen because we have some ability at reading residues, Mother. Better than most, in truth." So they had not been chosen simply because no one stronger was interested. There was a lesson in that. What Aes Sedai did was seldom as simple as it appeared on the surface. Egwene wished she could stop having to relearn lessons she had thought already learned. "Nisain is the best of us at that," Akarrin went on. "With your permission, Mother, I will let her answer." Nisain smoothed her dark woolen skirts nervously and cleared her throat. A gangly Gray with a strong chin and startlingly blue eyes, she had some small repute in matters of law and treaties, but she was obviously uneasy about speaking before the Hall. She looked straight at Egwene with the air of someone who did not want to actually see all the Sitters assembled. "Given the amount of saidar used there, Mother, it was no surprise to find the residues near as thick as the snow." More than a hint of Murandy clung to her tongue, a lilting sound. "Even after so long, I should have been able to grasp some idea of what was woven, if it was at all like anything I'm familiar with, but I have none. I could all but trace the weave, Mother, and it made no sense at all. None. In fact, it seemed so alien, it might not have been. . . . " Clearing her throat again, she swallowed. Her face grew a little paler. "It might not have been woven by a woman. We thought it must have been the Forsaken, of course, so I tested for resonance. We all did." Halfturning to gesture to her companions, she hurriedly turned back. She definitely preferred looking at Egwene to the Sitters, all leaning forward intently. "I can't say what was done, beyond scooping three miles out of the earth, or how it was done, but saidin was definitely used, too. The resonance was so strong, we should have been able to smell it. There was more saidin used than saidar, much more, Dragonmount beside a foothill. And that is all I can say, Mother." A sound fluttered through the pavilion, the sound of sisters letting out the breath they had been holding. Sheriam's exhalation seemed the loudest, but perhaps that was just because she was nearest.

ɛɡwin skuld əɹ feɪs tə stɪlnəs. ðə fɔɹseɪkən, ən ə wiv ðət kəd tɛɹ əweɪ hæf ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪf mɑlɪn dɪd pɹəpoʊz flaɪt, kəd ʃi tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk ðə sɪstɝz ɹɪmeɪn ən feɪs ðæt? kəd ʃi əbændən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ðə taʊɝ, ən ðə laɪt nu haʊ mɛni tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ə laɪvz? "dʌz ɛniwʌn ɛls əv ə kwɛstʃən?" ʃi æskt.

Egwene schooled her face to stillness. The Forsaken, and a weave that could tear away half of Tar Valon. If Malind did propose flight, could she try to make the sisters remain and face that? Could she abandon Tar Valon, and the Tower, and the Light knew how many tens of thousands of lives? "Does anyone else have a question?" she asked.

"aɪ hæv wʌn," ɹoʊmændə sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ toʊn. hɝ kɑm hæd nɑt kɹæk baɪ ə hɛɹ. "bʌt nɑt fəɹ ðiz sɪstɝz. ɪf noʊ wʌn əz ɛni fɝðɝ kwɛstʃənz fəɹ ðɛm, aɪm ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd laɪk tə bi əweɪ fɹəm hævɪŋ ðə hɔl stɛɹ ət ðɛm."

"I have one," Romanda said in a dry tone. Her calm had not cracked by a hair. "But not for these sisters. If no one has any further questions for them, I'm sure they would like to be away from having the Hall stare at them."

ɪt wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli hɝ pleɪs tə sədʒɛs ðæt, bʌt niðɝ wɑz ɪt pɹɪsaɪsli nɑt, soʊ ɛɡwin lɛɾ ɪt pæs. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd kwɛstʃənz fəɹ ækæɹən əɹ əɹ kəmpænjənz, əz ɪt tɝn aʊt, ən ɹoʊmændə ɔfɝɾ əm sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli wɔɹm θæŋks fəɹ ðɛɹ ɛfɝts. əɡɛn, nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli hɝ pleɪs.

It was not precisely her place to suggest that, but neither was it precisely not, so Egwene let it pass. No one else had questions for Akarrin or her companions, as it turned out, and Romanda offered them surprisingly warm thanks for their efforts. Again, not precisely her place.

"hu ɪz jəɹ kwɛstʃən fɔɹ?" ɛɡwin æskt əz ækæɹən ən ði ʌðɝ faɪv skæɾɝd tə dʒɔɪn ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ nʌmbɝz ə sɪstɝz kɹaʊɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə stænd-læmps ən bɹeɪʒɝz. ðeɪ wɝ iɡɝ, əz ɹoʊmændə hæd sɛd, tə ɡɛɾ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə hɔlz aɪz, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd wɑnə hɪɹ wʌt keɪm ə ðɛɹ wɝk. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi dɪfəkəl fəɹ ɛɡwin tə kip æspɹəɾi aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. ɹoʊmændə əfɛktəd nɑt tə noʊɾəs.

"Who is your question for?" Egwene asked as Akarrin and the other five scattered to join the growing numbers of sisters crowding among the stand-lamps and braziers. They were eager, as Romanda had said, to get out from under the Hall's eyes, but they did want to hear what came of their work. It was very difficult for Egwene to keep asperity out of her voice. Romanda affected not to notice.

əɹ pɝhæps dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs.

Or perhaps did not notice.

"fɔɹ mɔɹiə," ʃi sɛd. "wi səspɛktəd ðə fɔɹseɪkən fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. wi nu ðət wʌtɛvɝ hæpənd wɑz paʊɝfəl, ən fɑɹ əweɪ. ɔl wiv lɝnd, ɹɪli, ɪz ðət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪz ɡɔn, ən ə ðəɾ aɪ kən oʊnli seɪ, ðə wɝld ɪz bɛɾɝ ɔf wɪθaʊt ðət sɪŋkhoʊl ə ðə ʃædoʊ." ʃi fɪks ðə blu sɪɾɝ wɪð ə fɹaʊn ðət hæd meɪd mɛni ən ɛɛs sədaɪ skwɝm laɪk ə nɑvəs. "maɪ kwɛstʃən ɪz ðɪs. hæz ɛniθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd fəɹ ʌs?"

"For Moria," she said. "We suspected the Forsaken from the start. We knew that whatever happened was powerful, and far away. All we've learned, really, is that Shadar Logoth is gone, and of that I can only say, the world is better off without that sinkhole of the Shadow." She fixed the Blue Sitter with a frown that had made many an Aes Sedai squirm like a novice. "My question is this. Has anything changed for us?"

"ɪt ʃʊd," mɔɹiə ɹɪplaɪd, miɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz stɛɹ lɛvəli. ʃi maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn ɪn ðə hɔl əz lɔŋ əz ɹoʊmændə, bʌt sɪɾɝz wɝ ət list səpoʊzədli ɑn ən ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ. "wi hæv lɔŋ hæd pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz ɪn keɪs ðə fɔɹseɪkən də kʌm əɡɛnst ʌs. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ dʌz noʊ tə fɔɹm ə sɝkəl ɪf ʃi bi eɪbəl, əɹ dʒɔɪn wʌn ʃi dʌz faɪn fɔɹmɪŋ, əntɪl ɛvɹi sɝkəl dʌz ɹitʃ θɝtin. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz tə bi bɹɔɾ ɪn, ivən ðə nɑvəsɪz, ivən ðə nuəst." ləleɪn lʊkt ʌp əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli, bʌt haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi wɑntəd tə tʃaɪd mɔɹiə, ðeɪ wɝ ə ðə seɪm ədʒɑ. ðeɪ mʌst ɡɪv ət lis ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ə kɑmən fɹʌnt. ði ɛfɝɾ ə kipɪŋ əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt θɪn ləleɪnz lɪps, ðoʊ.

"It should," Moria replied, meeting the other woman's stare levelly. She might not have been in the Hall as long as Romanda, but Sitters were at least supposedly on an equal footing. "We have long had preparations in case the Forsaken do come against us. Every sister does know to form a circle if she be able, or join one she does find forming, until every circle does reach thirteen. Everyone is to be brought in, even the novices, even the newest." Lelaine looked up at her sharply, but however much she wanted to chide Moria, they were of the same Ajah. They must give at least the appearance of a common front. The effort of keeping her mouth shut thinned Lelaine's lips, though.

ɹoʊmændə wɑz ʌndɝ noʊ sətʃ kənstʃɹeɪnt. "mʌs jə ɪkspleɪn wʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn hɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi noʊz?

Romanda was under no such constraint. "Must you explain what everyone here already knows?

wəɹ ðə wʌnz u meɪd ðoʊz ɝeɪnʒmənts. pɝhæps juv fɝɡɑɾən?" ðɪs taɪm, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kʌɾɪŋ. oʊpən dɪspleɪz ʌv æŋɡɝ wɝ fɔɹbɪɾən ɪn ðə hɔl, bʌt nɑt ɡoʊɾɪŋ.

We are the ones who made those arrangements. Perhaps you have forgotten?" This time, her voice was cutting. Open displays of anger were forbidden in the Hall, but not goading.

ɪf mɔɹiə fɛl ðə pɹɪk, ðoʊ, ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ aʊtwɝd saɪn bɪɑn ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. "aɪ mʌst ɪkspleɪn fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, kəz wɪv noʊ θɔt fɑɹ ɪnʌf. mɑlɪnd, kən əɹ sɝkəlz stæn əɡɛnst wʌɾ ækæɹən ən naɪsən dɪskɹaɪbd?" dɪspaɪɾ əɹ fɪɹs aɪz, mɑlɪnz fʊl maʊθ ɔlweɪz lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə smaɪl, bʌt ʃi wɑz kwaɪt stɝn əz ʃi stʊd, ən ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ itʃ sɪɾɝ ɪn tɝn əz ɪf tə ɪmpɹɛs əɹ wɝdz ɑn ðɛm. "ðeɪ kænɑt. ivən ɪf wi ɹiɝeɪnʒ mæɾɝz soʊ ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst sɪstɝz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ɪn ðə seɪm sɝkəl - ən ðət minz ðeɪ mʌs lɪv, iɾ ən slip təɡɛðɝ, ɪf ðəɹ tə lɪŋk ɑn ðə moʊmənt -  ivən ðɛn, wi wəd bi maɪs feɪsɪŋ ə kæt. ɪnʌf maɪs kən oʊvɝwɛlm ivən ə lɑɹdʒ hʌŋɡɹi kæt, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ mɛni maɪs ɑɹ dɛd. ɪf ɪnʌf ə ðiz maɪs daɪ, ðoʊ, ðə waɪt taʊɝ daɪz." əɡɛn ðət ɹɪpəl ə saɪz ɹæn ðoʊ ðə pəvɪljən laɪk ən ənstɛɾi bɹiz. ɛɡwin mænədʒ tə kip əɹ feɪs kɑm, bʌt ʃi hæd tə fɔɹs əɹ fɪsts tə ɹɪlæks ðɛɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ skɝt. wɪtʃ wəd ðeɪ pɹəpoʊz, ən əsɔlt əɹ flaɪt? laɪt, haʊ kəd ʃi əpoʊz ðɛm? seɪm ədʒɑ əɹ nɑt, ləleɪn kəd teɪk ðə stʃɹeɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ.

If Moria felt the prick, though, she gave no outward sign beyond adjusting her shawl. "I must explain from the beginning, because we have no thought far enough. Malind, can our circles stand against what Akarrin and Nisain described?" Despite her fierce eyes, Malind's full mouth always looked ready to smile, but she was quite stern as she stood, and she stared at each Sitter in turn as if to impress her words on them. "They cannot. Even if we rearrange matters so the strongest sisters are always in the same circle - and that means they must live, eat and sleep together, if they're to link on the moment -  even then, we would be mice facing a cat. Enough mice can overwhelm even a large hungry cat, but not before many mice are dead. If enough of these mice die, though, the White Tower dies." Again that ripple of sighs ran though the pavilion like an unsteady breeze. Egwene managed to keep her face calm, but she had to force her fists to relax their grip on her skirt. Which would they propose, an assault or flight? Light, how could she oppose them? Same Ajah or not, Lelaine could take the strain no longer.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə sədʒɛstɪŋ, mɔɹiə?" ʃi snæpt. "ivən ɪf wi ɹiunaɪt ðə taʊɝ ðɪs vɛɹi deɪ, ðət woʊn tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæks." mɔɹiə smaɪl slaɪtli, əz ɪf ði ʌðɝ blu hæd sɛd dʒʌst wʌt ʃi wɑz hoʊpɪŋ sʌmwʌn wəd seɪ. "bʌt wi mʌs tʃeɪnʒ ðə fæks. ðə fækt ət pɹɛzən də bi ðəɾ əɹ stʃɹɔŋɡəst sɝkəlz bi tu wik. wi də hæv noʊ æŋɡɹil, mʌtʃ lɛs sɑŋɡɹil, soʊ wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm. ɪm noʊ sɝɾən ðəɹ bi ɛniθɪŋ ivən ɪn ðə taʊɝ ðət wəd meɪk ə lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf dɪfɝəns, ɛniweɪ. haʊ, ðɛn, də wi meɪk əɹ sɝkəlz stʃɹɔŋɝ? stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf, wi mʌs hoʊp, tə feɪs wʌt hæpən ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ən stɑp ɪt. ɛskɹɑldi, wʌɾ əv jə tə seɪ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ?"

"What are you suggesting, Moria?" she snapped. "Even if we reunite the Tower this very day, that won't change the facts." Moria smiled slightly, as if the other Blue had said just what she was hoping someone would say. "But we must change the facts. The fact at present do be that our strongest circles be too weak. We do have no angreal, much less sa'angreal, so we might as well ignore them. I'm no certain there be anything even in the Tower that would make a large enough difference, anyway. How, then, do we make our circles stronger? Strong enough, we must hope, to face what happened at Shadar Logoth and stop it. Escaralde, what have you to say on the matter?"

stɑɹɾəld, ɛɡwin lin fɔɹwɝd. ðeɪ wɝ wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. bʌt tə wʌɾ ɛnd? ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə ɹilaɪz ðət ðə θɹi sɪɾɝz u hæd kɔl ðə hɔl wɝ ɔl ɑn ðɛɹ fit. baɪ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ stændɪŋ, mɔɹiə ən mɑlɪn hæd meɪɾ ə klɪɹ dɛklɝeɪʃən. ɛskɹɑldi stʊd laɪk ə kwin, jɛt ðə taɪni bɹaʊn simd ɔl tu əwɛɹ ə ði aɪz slaɪɾɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ ən mɑlɪn ən mɔɹiə, ðə θɔtfəl fɹaʊnz ən tu-stɪl feɪsəz. ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl twaɪs bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ lɛktʃɝɪŋ ə klæs, hɝ vɔɪs θɪn jɛt fɔɹsfəl.

Startled, Egwene leaned forward. They were working together. But to what end? She was not the only one to realize that the three Sitters who had called the Hall were all on their feet. By remaining standing, Moria and Malind had made a clear declaration. Escaralde stood like a queen, yet the tiny Brown seemed all too aware of the eyes sliding between her and Malind and Moria, the thoughtful frowns and too-still faces. She shifted her shawl twice before speaking. She sounded as though she were lecturing a class, her voice thin yet forceful.

"ði eɪntʃən lɪɾɝətʃɝ ɪz kwaɪt klɪɹ, ðoʊ lɪɾəl stʌɾid, aɪ fɪɹ. ɪt ɡæðɝz dʌst ɹæðɝ ðən ɹiɾɝz. ɹaɪɾɪŋz kəlɛktəɾ ɪn ði ɝliəs jɪɹz ə ðə taʊɝ meɪk ɪt pleɪn ðət sɝkəlz wɝ nɑt lɪməɾəd tə θɝtin, ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðə pɹɪsaɪs mɛkənɪzəm - aɪ ʃəd seɪ, ðə pɹɪsaɪs bæləns - ɪz ənnoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi tu dɪfəkəl tə wɝk aʊt. fəɹ ðoʊz ə jə hu hæv nɑt spɛn ðə taɪm jə ʃəɾ əv ɪn ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi, ðə mænɝ ʌv ɪnkɹisɪŋ ðə saɪz ʌv ə sɝkəl ɪnvɑlvz . . . " fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ʃi fɔltɝd, ən vɪzəbli fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə kəntɪnju. " . . . ɪnvɑlvz ði ɪnkluʒən ə mɛn u kən tʃænəl."

"The ancient literature is quite clear, though little studied, I fear. It gathers dust rather than readers. Writings collected in the earliest years of the Tower make it plain that circles were not limited to thirteen, in the Age of Legends. The precise mechanism - I should say, the precise balance - is unknown, but it should not be too difficult to work out. For those of you who have not spent the time you should have in the Tower library, the manner of increasing the size of a circle involves . . . " For the first time, she faltered, and visibly forced herself to continue. " . . . involves the inclusion of men who can channel."

feɪsɛl pɑp tə hɝ fit. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə sədʒɛstɪŋ?" ʃi dɪmændəɾ ən sæt daʊn ɪmiɾiətli, əz ðoʊ sʌmwʌn maɪt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn səpɔɹt.

Faiselle popped to her feet. "What are you suggesting?" she demanded and sat down immediately, as though someone might think she was standing in support.

"aɪ də æsk ðət ðə hɔl bi klɪɹd!" mæɡlə sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. laɪk mɔɹiə, ʃi wɑz ɪliɑnɝ, ən ædʒəteɪʃən θɪkən əɹ æksɛn mɑɹkədli. "ðɪs də noʊ bi ə mæɾɝ fəɹ dɪskʌʃən bɪfɔɹ ɛni seɪv ðə hɔl ɪn kloʊz sɪɾɪŋ." ʃi, tu, dʒɹɑp bæk ɑntu hɝ bɛntʃ əz sun əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt, ən sæt ɡlaʊɝɪŋ, waɪd ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt ən hænz oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ ɑn əɹ skɝts.

"I do ask that the Hall be cleared!" Magla said, rising. Like Moria, she was Illianer, and agitation thickened her accent markedly. "This do no be a matter for discussion before any save the Hall in closed sitting." She, too, dropped back onto her bench as soon as she finished, and sat glowering, wide shoulders hunched and hands opening and closing on her skirts.

"aɪ də fɪɹ ɪt bi tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt," mɔɹiə sɛd laʊdli. ʃi hæd tə spik laʊdli, tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə mɝmɝ ə sɪstɝz tɔkɪŋ ɪksaɪɾədli bɪhaɪn ðə bɛntʃɪz, ə hʌm laɪk ə hjudʒ bihaɪv. "wʌɾ əz bɪn sɛɾ əz bɪn sɛd, ən hɝd baɪ tu mɛni sɪstɝz fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə tʃɹaɪ ʃʌɾɪŋ ðə wɝdz əweɪ naʊ." hɝ bʊzəm ɹoʊz əz ʃi pʊld ɪn ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs ə nɑtʃ laʊɾɝ. "aɪ də pʊt bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl ðə pɹəpoʊzəl ðət wi də ɛntɝ ɪndə ən əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə blæk taʊɝ, ðət wi meɪ bɹɪŋ mɛn ɪndə əɹ sɝkəlz ət nid." ɪf ʃi saʊndəɾ ə tʃɹaɪfəl stʃɹæŋɡəld ət ði ɛnd, ɪt wɑz noʊ wʌndɝ. fju ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd seɪ ðət neɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɪmoʊʃən, dɪsɡʌst ɪf nɑɾ aʊtʃɹaɪt heɪtʃɹəd. ɪt stʃɹʌk əɡɛns ðə bʌz ə vɔɪsəz - ən pɹədust æbsəlut saɪləns fəɹ ðə speɪs ə θɹi hɑɹtbits. "ðæɾ ɪz mædnəs!" ʃɛɹiəmz ʃɹik ʃæɾɝd ðə stɪlnəs ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn. ðə kipɝ dɪd nɑɾ ɛntɝ dɪskʌʃənz ɪn ðə hɔl. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən ɛntɝ ðə hɔl ɪtsɛlf wɪθaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn. feɪs flʌɾɪŋ wɪð ɹɛd, ʃɛɹiəm dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, pɝhæps tə feɪs ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl ɹibjuk, pɝhæps tə dɪfɛn hɝsɛlf. ðə hɔl hæɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɑn ɪts maɪn ðən ɹibjukɪŋ hɝ, ðoʊ.

"I do fear it be too late for that," Moria said loudly. She had to speak loudly, to be heard over the murmur of sisters talking excitedly behind the benches, a hum like a huge beehive. "What has been said has been said, and heard by too many sisters for anyone to try shutting the words away now." Her bosom rose as she pulled in a deep breath, and she raised her voice a notch louder. "I do put before the Hall the proposal that we do enter into an agreement with the Black Tower, that we may bring men into our circles at need." If she sounded a trifle strangled at the end, it was no wonder. Few Aes Sedai could say that name without emotion, disgust if not outright hatred. It struck against the buzz of voices - and produced absolute silence for the space of three heartbeats. "That is madness!" Sheriam's shriek shattered the stillness in more ways than one. The Keeper did not enter discussions in the Hall. She could not even enter the Hall itself without the Amyrlin. Face flooding with red, Sheriam drew herself up, perhaps to face the inevitable rebuke, perhaps to defend herself. The Hall had other things on its mind than rebuking her, though.

lipɪŋ ʌp fɹəm ðɛɹ bɛntʃɪz dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ wɝdz aʊt, sɪɾɝz bɪɡæn tə spik, tə ʃaʊt, səmtaɪmz ɑn tɑp ʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Leaping up from their benches just long enough to get their words out, Sitters began to speak, to shout, sometimes on top of one another.

"mædnəs hɑɹdli bɪɡɪnz tə dɪskɹaɪb ɪt!" feɪsɛl ʃaʊɾəd, ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət vɛɹɪlɪn kɹaɪd, "haʊ kən wi ælaɪ aʊɝsɛlvz wɪð mɛn u kən tʃænəl?"

"Madness hardly begins to describe it!" Faiselle shouted, at the same time that Varilin cried, "How can we ally ourselves with men who can channel?"

"ðiz soʊ-kɔld æʃəmən ɑɹ teɪntɪd!" sɛɝɔɪjə kɔld aʊt wɪð noʊ saɪn ə ðə vɔntɪd waɪɾ ədʒɑ ɹɪzɝv. hænz nɑɾɪd ɪn əɹ ʃɔl, ʃi tʃɹɛmbəl soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðə lɔŋ snoʊi fɹɪnʒ sweɪd.

"These so-called Asha'man are tainted!" Saroiya called out with no sign of the vaunted White Ajah reserve. Hands knotted in her shawl, she trembled so hard that the long snowy fringe swayed.

"teɪntɪd wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ!"

"Tainted with the Dark One's touch!"

"ivən sədʒɛstɪŋ sətʃ ə θɪŋ pʊts əs əɡɛnst ɔl ðə waɪt taʊɝ stænz fɔɹ," tɑkimə sɛd ɹʌfli. "wi wəd bi dɪspaɪz baɪ ɛvɹi wʊmən u kɔlz hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ, baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ lɔŋ ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪvz!"

"Even suggesting such a thing puts us against all the White Tower stands for," Takima said roughly. "We would be despised by every woman who calls herself Aes Sedai, by Aes Sedai long in their graves!"

mæɡlə wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə ʃeɪk ə fɪst, wɪð ə fjʊɹi ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ətɛmp tə mæsk. "oʊnli ə dɑɹkfɹɛn kəd sədʒɛs ðɪs! oʊnli ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd!" mɔɹiə peɪld ət ði ækjəzeɪʃən, ðən wɛn bɹaɪt ɹɛd wɪð æŋɡɝ ə hɝ oʊn.

Magla went so far as to shake a fist, with a fury she did not attempt to mask. "Only a Darkfriend could suggest this! Only a Darkfriend!" Moria paled at the accusation, then went bright red with anger of her own.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ʃi stʊɾ ɑn ðɪs. ðə blæk taʊɝ wɑz ɹændz kɹieɪʃən, ən pɝhæps nɛsəsɛɹi, ɪf ðəɹ wɑz tə bi ɛni hoʊp ʌv wɪnɪŋ ðə læs bæɾəl, jɛt ði æʃəmən wɝ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, ə θɪŋ fɪɹd fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, ən ðeɪ tʃænəld ʃædoʊ-steɪn seɪɾɪn.

Egwene did not know where she stood on this. The Black Tower was Rand's creation, and perhaps necessary, if there was to be any hope of winning the Last Battle, yet the Asha'man were men who could channel, a thing feared for three thousand years, and they channeled Shadow-stained saidin.

ɹænd hɪmsɛlf wɑz ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl, jɛt wɪθaʊt hɪm, ðə ʃædoʊ wəd wɪn ət tɑɹmən ɡdən. ðə laɪt hɛlp əɹ fəɹ siɪŋ ɪt soʊ koʊldli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tʃɹuθ. wɛɹɛvɝ ʃi stʊɾ ɑn ðə mæɾɝ, mæɾɝz wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hæn ðəɹ ən ðɛn. ɛskɹɑldi wɑz ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪnsʌls wɪð feɪsɛl, boʊθ ət ðə tɑps ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz. oʊpən ɪnsʌls!

Rand himself was a man who could channel, yet without him, the Shadow would win at Tarmon Gai'don. The Light help her for seeing it so coldly, but it was hard truth. Wherever she stood on the matter, matters were getting out of hand there and then. Escaralde was exchanging insults with Faiselle, both at the tops of their lungs. Open insults!

ɪn ðə hɔl! sɛɝɔɪjə hæɾ əbændən ðə læst ʃɹɛdz ʌv waɪɾ ədʒɑ kulnəs ən wɑz skɹimɪŋ ət mɑlɪnd, hu skɹim bæk, niðɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə wʌndɝ ɪf iðɝ kəɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌt ði ʌðɝ wɑz seɪɪŋ, ən pɝhæps ə blɛsɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, niðɝ ɹoʊmændə nɔɹ ləleɪn hæɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðeɪ sæt stɛɹɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ənblɪŋkɪŋ. laɪkli itʃ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹid haʊ ði ʌðɝ wəd stæn dʒʌst soʊ ʃi kəd stæn ɪn ɑpəzɪʃən. mæɡlə ɡɑt daʊn fɹəm əɹ bɛntʃ ən stɔk təwɔɹd mɔɹiə wɪð ðə ɡlɛɹ ə sʌmwʌn iɡɝ tə kʌm tə bloʊz. nɑt wɝdz, bʌt fɪsts. mæɡləz wɝ klɛntʃt əɾ əɹ saɪdz. hɝ vaɪn-wɝkt ʃɔl slɪɾ ɔf ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts, ənnoʊɾɪst.

In the Hall! Saroiya had abandoned the last shreds of White Ajah coolness and was screaming at Malind, who screamed back, neither waiting on the other. It would have been a wonder if either could understand what the other was saying, and perhaps a blessing if they could not. Surprisingly, neither Romanda nor Lelaine had opened her mouth since the beginning. They sat staring at one another, unblinking. Likely each was trying to read how the other would stand just so she could stand in opposition. Magla got down from her bench and stalked toward Moria with the glare of someone eager to come to blows. Not words, but fists. Magla's were clenched at her sides. Her vine-worked shawl slid off onto the carpets, unnoticed.

stændɪŋ, ɛɡwin ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs. ɪksɛp fəɹ sɝɾən ɪɡzækli pɹiskɹaɪb fʌŋkʃənz, tʃænəlɪŋ wɑz fɔɹbɪɾən ɪn ðə hɔl - ənʌðɝ ə ðə kʌstəmz ðət pɔɪntəd tə dɑɹkɝ deɪz ɪn ðə hɔlz hɪstɝi - bʌt ʃi meɪɾ ə sɪmpəl wiv ʌv ɛɹ ən faɪɝ. "ə pɹəpoʊzəl əz bɪn leɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl," ʃi sɛd, ən ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ. ðət wɑz nɑɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪt wʌns hæd bɪn. nɑɾ izi, nɑt kloʊs tə izi, bʌt nɑɾ əz hɑɹd. ə mɛmɹi ʌv ðə paʊɝz switnəs ɹɪmeɪnd, ɪnʌf tə səsteɪn əɹ əntɪl ðə nɛks taɪm.

Standing, Egwene embraced the Source. Except for certain exactly prescribed functions, channeling was forbidden in the Hall - another of the customs that pointed to darker days in the Hall's history - but she made a simple weave of Air and Fire. "A proposal has been laid before the Hall," she said, and released saidar. That was not as hard as it once had been. Not easy, not close to easy, but not as hard. A memory of the Power's sweetness remained, enough to sustain her until the next time.

mæɡnəfaɪd baɪ ðə wiv, hɝ wɝdz bumd ɪn ðə pəvɪljən laɪk θʌndɝ. ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɹæŋk bæk, wɪnsɪŋ ən kʌvɝɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪɹz. ðə saɪləns æftɝ simd ɪnkɹɛɾəbli laʊd. mæɡlə ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt, ðən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ hæfweɪ tə ðə blu bɛntʃɪz. heɪstəli ənluzɪŋ əɹ fɪsts, ʃi pɔz tə snætʃ ʌp əɹ ʃɔl ən hɝid bæk tə hɝ oʊn sit. ʃɛɹiəm stʊd wipɪŋ oʊpənli. ʃʊɹli ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ðət laʊd. "ə pɹəpoʊzəl əz bɪn leɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə hɔl," ɛɡwin ɹɪpiɾɪd ɪndə ðə saɪləns. æftɝ ðət paʊɝ-mæɡnəfaɪd blɛɹ, hɝ vɔɪs ɹæŋ ɪn əɹ oʊn ɪɹz. pɝhæps ɪt hæd bɪn laʊɾɝ ðən ʃi θɔt. ðət wiv hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɪntɛndəd fəɹ jus ɪnsaɪd wɔlz, ivən pætʃt kænvəs wɔlz. "haʊ spik jə ɪn səpɔɹɾ ʌv ən əlaɪəns wɪð ðə blæk taʊɝ, mɔɹiə?" ʃi sæt daʊn əz sun əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt. haʊ dɪd ʃi stæn ɑn ðɪs? wʌt dɪfəkəltiz wəɾ ɪt pɹizɛn hɝ? haʊ kəɾ ɪt bi juz tə ædvæntɪdʒ? ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ɪndid. ðoʊz wɝ ðə fɝs tu θɪŋz tə kʌm tə maɪnd. ʃi wɪʃt ʃɛɹiəm wəd dʒɹaɪ hɝ aɪz ən stʃɹeɪɾən əɹ bækboʊn. ʃi wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ʃi niɾəd ə kipɝ, nɑɾ ə mɪlksɑp. ɪt tʊk ə fju mɪnəts fəɹ ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹɪstɔɹ ɪtsɛlf, sɪɾɝz stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ kloʊðz ən smuðɪŋ skɝts ənnɛsəsɛɹəli, əvɔɪɾɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝz aɪz ən ɪspɛʃli nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət ðə wɑtʃɪŋ sɪstɝz kɹaʊɾəd bɪhaɪn ðə bɛntʃɪz. səm sɪɾɝz feɪsəz bɪkeɪm steɪnd wɪð ɹɛd ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð æŋɡɝ. sɪɾɝz dɪd nɑt ʃɹik ət wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk fɑɹmhænz ət ʃɪɹɪŋ. moʊst ɪspɛʃli nɑɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz.

Magnified by the weave, her words boomed in the pavilion like thunder. Aes Sedai shrank back, wincing and covering their ears. The silence after seemed incredibly loud. Magla gaped at her in astonishment, then gave a start at realizing that she was standing halfway to the Blue benches. Hastily unloosing her fists, she paused to snatch up her shawl and hurried back to her own seat. Sheriam stood weeping openly. Surely it had not been that loud.
