The thatchroofed houses were vague, in the manner of dreams - sometimes the roofs were slate; sometimes the houses seemed of stone, sometimes wood - but he was sharp and clear, dressed in a fine green coat and that wide-brimmed black hat, just as he had been the day he rode into Salidar. There was not another human being in sight. Rubbing the ball between his hands, he took a short run and casually rolled it across the smooth grass. All nine pins fell, scattered as if they had been kicked. Mat turned and picked up another ball, and the pins were back upright. No, there was a fresh set of pins. The old still lay where they had fallen. He hurled the ball again, a lazy underhanded bowl. And Egwene wanted to scream. The pins were not turned pieces of wood. They were men, standing there watching the ball roll toward them. None moved until the ball sent them flying. Mat turned to pick up another ball, and there were more new pins, new men, standing in orderly formation among the men lying sprawled on the ground as if dead. No, they were dead.

ʌnkənsɝnd, mæt boʊld.

Unconcerned, Mat bowled.

ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹu dʒɹim; ʃi nu ðət lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪt feɪɾəd. ə ɡlɪmps ʌv ə fjutʃɝ ðət maɪt kʌm tə pæs, ə wɔɹnɪŋ ʌv wʌt ʃəd bi wɑtʃt fɔɹ. tʃɹu dʒɹimz wɝ ɔlweɪz pɑsəbɪləɾiz, nɑt sɝɾəntiz -  ʃi ɔfən hæd tə ɹimaɪn hɝsɛlf ə ðæt; dʒɹimɪŋ wɑz nɑt fɔɹtɛlɪŋ - bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə daɪɹ pɑsəbɪləɾi.

It was a true dream; she knew that long before it faded. A glimpse of a future that might come to pass, a warning of what should be watched for. True dreams were always possibilities, not certainties -  she often had to remind herself of that; Dreaming was not Foretelling - but this was a dire possibility.

ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðoʊz hjumən pɪnz hæd ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd θaʊzənz ə mɛn. ʌv ðæt, ʃi wɑz sɝɾən. ən ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. mæt hæd mɛɾ ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ wʌns, bʌt ðət wɑz lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðɪs wɑz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɹisənt. ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz wɝ skæɾɝd, ðɛɹ ɡɪldhaʊsɪz ɡɔn. wʌn wɑz ivən wɝkɪŋ əɹ kɹæft wɪð ə tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ðəɾ ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð fəɹ ə taɪm. mæt maɪt faɪn ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ ɛniwɛɹ. stɪl, ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pɑsəbəl fjutʃɝ. blik ən blʌdsteɪnd, bʌɾ oʊnli pɑsəbəl. jɛt ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ʌv ɪɾ ət lis twaɪs. nɑt ðə seɪm dʒɹim, ɪɡzækli, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ðə seɪm minɪŋ. dɪd ðət meɪk ɪt mɔɹ laɪkli tə kʌm tə pæs? ʃi wəɾ əv tə æsk ðə waɪz wʌnz tə faɪn aʊt, ən ʃi wɑz ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɹɪlʌktən tə də ðæt. ɛvɹi kwɛstʃən ʃi æskt ɹɪvil sʌmθɪŋ tə ðɛm, ən ðɛɹ ɡoʊlz wɝ nɑt hɝz. tə seɪv wʌt ðeɪ kəɾ ə ði il, ðeɪ wəd lɛt ðə waɪt taʊɝ bi ɡɹaʊn tə dʌst.

Every one of those human pins had represented thousands of men. Of that, she was certain. And an Illuminator was part of it. Mat had met an Illuminator once, but that was long ago. This was something more recent. The Illuminators were scattered, their guildhouses gone. One was even working her craft with a traveling show that Elayne and Nynaeve had traveled with for a time. Mat might find an Illuminator anywhere. Still, it was only a possible future. Bleak and bloodstained, but only possible. Yet she had dreamed of it at least twice. Not the same dream, exactly, but always the same meaning. Did that make it more likely to come to pass? She would have to ask the Wise Ones to find out, and she was increasingly reluctant to do that. Every question she asked revealed something to them, and their goals were not hers. To save what they could of the Aiel, they would let the White Tower be ground to dust.

ʃi hæd mɔɹ ðən ɛni wʌn pipəl, ɛni wʌn neɪʃən, tə θɪŋk ʌv. mɔɹ dʒɹimz.

She had more than any one people, any one nation, to think of. More dreams.

ʃi wɑz stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ʌp ə nɛɹoʊ, ɹɑki pæθ əlɔŋ ðə feɪs ʌv ə taʊɝɪŋ klɪf. klaʊdz sɝaʊndəd hɝ, haɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ ən ðə kɹɛst əbʌv, jɛt ʃi nu ðət boʊθ wɝ vɛɹi fɑɹ əweɪ. ʃi hæd tə pleɪs əɹ fit vɛɹi kɛɹfəli. ðə pæθ wɑz ə kɹæk lɛdʒ bɛɹli waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə stæn ɑn wɪð wʌn ʃoʊldɝ pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə klɪf, ə lɛdʒ lɪɾɝd wɪð stoʊnz əz lɑɹdʒ əz əɹ fɪs ðət kəd tɝn ʌndɝ ə mɪspleɪst stɛp ən sɛn əɹ hɝtlɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst sim ðɪs wɑz laɪk ðə dʒɹimz ə pʊʃɪŋ mɪlstoʊnz ən pʊlɪŋ kɑɹts, jɛt ʃi nu ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹu dʒɹim. əbɹʌpli, ðə lɛdʒ dʒɹɑpt əweɪ fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ wɪð ðə kɹæk ə kɹʌmbəlɪŋ stoʊn, ən ʃi kɑt fɹæntəkəli ət ðə klɪf, fɪŋɡɝz skɹæbəlɪŋ tə faɪn ə hoʊld. hɝ fɪŋɡɝtɪps slɪɾ ɪndə ə taɪni kɹɛvəs, ən əɹ fɔl stɑpt wɪð ə dʒoʊl ðət ɹɛntʃt əɹ ɑɹmz. fit dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə klaʊdz, ʃi lɪsən tə ðə fɔlɪŋ stoʊn kɹæʃ əɡɛns ðə klɪf əntɪl ðə saʊn feɪɾəd tə nʌθɪŋ wɪθaʊt ðə stoʊn ɛvɝ hɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. dɪmli, ʃi kəd si ðə bɹoʊkən lɛdʒ tə hɝ lɛft. tɛn fiɾ əweɪ, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə maɪl ɔf fəɹ ɔl ðə tʃæns ʃi hæɾ ə ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt. ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən, ðə mɪsts hɪd wʌtɛvɝ ɹɪmeɪn ə ðə pæθ, bʌt ʃi θɔɾ ɪt hæd tə bi fɑɹðɝ əweɪ stɪl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz. ʃi kəd nɑt pʊl hɝsɛlf ʌp, oʊnli hæŋ ðəɹ baɪ hɝ fɪŋɡɝtɪps əntɪl ʃi fɛl. ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kɹɛvəs simd əz ʃɑɹp əz ə naɪf ʌndɝ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz.

She was struggling up a narrow, rocky path along the face of a towering cliff. Clouds surrounded her, hiding the ground below and the crest above, yet she knew that both were very far away. She had to place her feet very carefully. The path was a cracked ledge barely wide enough for her to stand on with one shoulder pressed against the cliff, a ledge littered with stones as large as her fist that could turn under a misplaced step and send her hurtling over the edge. It almost seemed this was like the dreams of pushing millstones and pulling carts, yet she knew it was a true dream. Abruptly, the ledge dropped away from under her with the crack of crumbling stone, and she caught frantically at the cliff, fingers scrabbling to find a hold. Her fingertips slid into a tiny crevice, and her fall stopped with a jolt that wrenched her arms. Feet dangling into the clouds, she listened to the falling stone crash against the cliff until the sound faded to nothing without the stone ever hitting the ground. Dimly, she could see the broken ledge to her left. Ten feet away, it might as well have been a mile off for all the chance she had of reaching it. In the other direction, the mists hid whatever remained of the path, but she thought it had to be farther away still. There was no strength in her arms. She could not pull herself up, only hang there by her fingertips until she fell. The edge of the crevice seemed as sharp as a knife under her fingers.

sʌɾənli ə wʊmən əpɪɹd, klæmbɝɪŋ daʊn ðə ʃɪɹ saɪɾ ə ðə klɪf aʊɾ ə ðə klaʊdz, meɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ əz dɛfli əz ɪf ʃi wɝ wɔkɪŋ daʊn stɛɹz. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɔɹd stʃɹæp tə hɝ bæk.

Suddenly a woman appeared, clambering down the sheer side of the cliff out of the clouds, making her way as deftly as if she were walking down stairs. There was a sword strapped to her back.

hɝ feɪs weɪvɝd, nɛvɝ sɛɾəlɪŋ klɪɹli, bʌt ðə sɔɹd simd əz sɑləɾ əz ðə stoʊn. ðə wʊmən ɹitʃt ɛɡwinz lɛvəl ən hɛld aʊt wʌn hænd. "wi kən ɹitʃ ðə tɑp təɡɛðɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə fəmɪljɝ dʒɹɔlɪŋ æksɛnt.

Her face wavered, never settling clearly, but the sword seemed as solid as the stone. The woman reached Egwene's level and held out one hand. "We can reach the top together," she said in a familiar drawling accent.

ɛɡwin pʊʃt ðə dʒɹim əweɪ əz ʃi wəɾ əv ə vaɪpɝ. ʃi fɛlt əɹ bɑɾi θɹæʃ, hɝd hɝsɛlf ɡɹoʊn ɪn əɹ slip, bʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi kəd də nʌθɪŋ. ʃi hæd dʒɹimd ə ðə sintʃæn bɪfɔɹ, ʌv ə sintʃæn wʊmən sʌmhaʊ taɪd tə hɝ, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə sintʃæn u wəd seɪv hɝ. noʊ!

Egwene pushed the dream away as she would have a viper. She felt her body thrash, heard herself groan in her sleep, but for a moment she could do nothing. She had dreamed of the Seanchan before, of a Seanchan woman somehow tied to her, but this was a Seanchan who would save her. No!

ðeɪ hæd pʊɾ ə liʃ ɑn hɝ, meɪɾ əɹ deɪmeɪn. ʃi wəɾ əz sun daɪ əz bi seɪv baɪ ə sintʃæn! ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm pæs bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ædʒɹɛs hɝsɛlf tə kɑmɪŋ əɹ slipɪŋ bɑɾi. əɹ meɪbi ɪɾ oʊnli simd ə lɔŋ taɪm. nɑɾ ə sintʃæn; nɛvɝ ðæt!

They had put a leash on her, made her damane. She would as soon die as be saved by a Seanchan! A very long time passed before she could address herself to calming her sleeping body. Or maybe it only seemed a long time. Not a Seanchan; never that!

sloʊli, ðə dʒɹimz ɹɪtɝnd.

Slowly, the dreams returned.

ʃi wɑz klaɪmɪŋ ənʌðɝ pæθ əlɔŋ ə klɪf ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɪn klaʊdz, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə bɹɔd lɛdʒ ə smuðli peɪvd waɪt stoʊn, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹɑks ʌndɝfʊt. ðə klɪf ɪtsɛlf wɑz tʃæki waɪɾ ən əz smuð əz ɪf pɑlɪʃt. dɪspaɪt ðə klaʊdz, ðə peɪl stoʊn ɔlmoʊst ɡlimd. ʃi klaɪm kwɪkli ən sun ɹilaɪz ðət ðə lɛdʒ wɑz spaɪɹəlɪŋ ɝaʊnd. ðə klɪf wɑz æktʃəli  ə spaɪɹ. noʊ sunɝ dɪd ðət θɔɾ əkɝ ðən ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɑn ðə tɑp ʌv ɪt, ə flæt pɑlɪʃt dɪsk wɔl baɪ mɪst. nɑt kwaɪt flæt, ðoʊ. ə smɔl waɪt plɪnθ stʊd sɛntɝɾ ɪn ðət sɝkəl, səpɔɹɾɪŋ ən ɔɪl-læmp meɪɾ ə klɪɹ ɡlæs. ðə fleɪm ɑn ðət læmp bɝn bɹaɪɾ ən stɛɾi, wɪθaʊt flɪkɝɪŋ. ɪt wɑz waɪt, tu.

She was climbing another path along a cliff shrouded in clouds, but this was a broad ledge of smoothly paved white stone, and there were no rocks underfoot. The cliff itself was chalky white and as smooth as if polished. Despite the clouds, the pale stone almost gleamed. She climbed quickly and soon realized that the ledge was spiraling around. The cliff was actually a spire. No sooner did that thought occur than she was standing on the top of it, a flat polished disc walled by mist. Not quite flat, though. A small white plinth stood centered in that circle, supporting an oil-lamp made of clear glass. The flame on that lamp burned bright and steady, without flickering. It was white, too.

sʌɾənli ə pɛɹ ə bɝdz flæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə mɪst, tu ɹeɪvənz blæk əz naɪt. stʃɹikɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə spaɪɹ-tɑp, ðeɪ stʃɹʌk ðə læmp ən flu ɑn wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə pɔz. ðə læmp spʌn ən wɑbəld, dænsɪŋ ɝaʊn ətɑp ðə plɪnθ, flɪŋɪŋ ɔf dʒɹɑpləts ʌv ɔɪl. səm ə ðoʊz dʒɹɑps kɑt faɪɝ ɪn mɪdɛɹ ən vænɪʃt. ʌðɝz fɛl ɝaʊn ðə ʃɔɹt kɑləm, itʃ səpɔɹɾɪŋ ə taɪni, flɪkɝɪŋ waɪt fleɪm. ən ðə læmp kəntɪnjud tə wɑbəl ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə fɔlɪŋ. ɛɡwin woʊk ɪn dɑɹknəs wɪð ə dʒoʊlt. ʃi nu. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ʃi nu ɪɡzækli wʌɾ ə dʒɹim mɛnt. bʌt waɪ wəd ʃi dʒɹim ʌv ə sintʃæn wʊmən seɪvɪŋ hɝ, ən ðən ə ðə sintʃæn ətækɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ? ən ətæk ðət wəd ʃeɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ðɛɹ kɔɹ ən θɹɛɾən ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə pɑsəbɪləɾi. bʌt ði ɪvɛns sin ɪn tʃɹu dʒɹimz wɝ mɔɹ laɪkli ðən ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz.

Suddenly a pair of birds flashed out of the mist, two ravens black as night. Streaking across the spire-top, they struck the lamp and flew on without so much as a pause. The lamp spun and wobbled, dancing around atop the plinth, flinging off droplets of oil. Some of those drops caught fire in midair and vanished. Others fell around the short column, each supporting a tiny, flickering white flame. And the lamp continued to wobble on the edge of falling. Egwene woke in darkness with a jolt. She knew. For the first time, she knew exactly what a dream meant. But why would she dream of a Seanchan woman saving her, and then of the Seanchan attacking the White Tower? An attack that would shake the Aes Sedai to their core and threaten the Tower itself. Of course, it was only a possibility. But the events seen in true dreams were more likely than other possibilities.

ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ kɑmli, bʌɾ əɾ ə ɹʌf ɹʌsəl ə kænvəs fɹəm ði ɛntʃɹi flæps, ʃi vɛɹi nɪɹli ɛmbɹeɪs ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. heɪstəli ʃi ɹæn θɹu nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪzəz tə kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf, wɔɾɝ floʊɪŋ oʊvɝ smuð stoʊnz, wɪn bloʊɪŋ θɹu haɪ ɡɹæs. laɪt, ʃi hæd bɪn fɹaɪɾənd. ɪt tʊk tu tə ətʃiv ɛni sɔɹɾ ə kɑm. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə æsk u wɑz ðɛɹ. "əslip?" hɑliməz vɔɪs mʌɾɝd sɔfli. ʃi saʊndəd waʊn ʌp taɪt, ɔlmoʊst ɪksaɪɾəd. "wɛl, aɪ wʊdn maɪn ə ɡʊd naɪts slip maɪsɛlf."

She thought she was considering calmly, but at a rough rustle of canvas from the entry flaps, she very nearly embraced the True Source. Hastily she ran through novice exercises to compose herself, water flowing over smooth stones, wind blowing through high grass. Light, she had been frightened. It took two to achieve any sort of calm. She opened her mouth to ask who was there. "Asleep?" Halima's voice muttered softly. She sounded wound up tight, almost excited. "Well, I wouldn't mind a good night's sleep myself."

lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wʊmən əndʒɹɛs fəɹ bɛɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ɛɡwin leɪ vɛɹi stɪl. ɪf ʃi lɛɾ əɹ noʊ ʃi wɑz əweɪk, ʃi wəɾ əv tə tɔk wɪð hɝ, ən ət ðə moʊmənt, ðət wəd bi ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ. ʃi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ðət hɑlimə hæd faʊn hɝsɛlf kʌmpəni, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə hoʊl naɪt. hɑlimə kəd də əz ʃi wɪʃt, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz stɪl dɪsəpɔɪntɪd. wɪʃɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd ɹɪmeɪn əslip, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf slɪpɪŋ ʌndɝ wʌns mɔɹ, ən ðɪs taɪm, ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hæfweɪ. ʃi wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni dʒɹimz ðət keɪm, ən ʃi dɪd nid səm æktʃəwəl slip. tʃɛsə keɪm bɹaɪɾ ən ɝli tə bɹɪŋ əɹ bɹɛkfəst ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ ən hɛlp əɹ dʒɹɛs. æktʃəli , ɪt wɑz ɝli ən nɑt bɹaɪɾ əɾ ɔl. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə mɛɹəs hɪn ə sʌnlaɪt, ən ðə læmps' laɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə si ɛniθɪŋ. ði ɛmbɝz ɪn ðə bɹeɪziɝ hæd daɪd daʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðə koʊl ðət hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ fɛlt ɡɹeɪ. ðəɹ maɪt bi ə tʃæns ə mɔɹ snoʊ tədeɪ. hɑlimə ɹɪəld ɪndə hɝ sɪlk ʃɪft ən dʒɹɛs, meɪkɪŋ læfɪŋ dʒoʊks əbaʊt haʊ ʃi wəd laɪk tə hæv ə meɪd waɪl tʃɛsə wɑz duɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊz ə bʌɾənz ðət ɹæn daʊn ɛɡwinz bæk. ðə plʌmp wʊmən wɔɹ ə sɛt feɪs, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ hɑlimə ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ɛɡwin sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Listening to the woman undress for bed in the dark, Egwene lay very still. If she let her know she was awake, she would have to talk with her, and at the moment, that would be embarrassing. She was fairly certain that Halima had found herself company, if not for the whole night. Halima could do as she wished, of course, but Egwene was still disappointed. Wishing that she had remained asleep, she found herself slipping under once more, and this time, she did not try to stop halfway. She would remember any dreams that came, and she did need some actual sleep. Chesa came bright and early to bring her breakfast on a tray and help her dress. Actually, it was early and not bright at all. There was only the merest hint of sunlight, and the lamps' light was necessary to see anything. The embers in the brazier had died down during the night, of course, and the cold that hung in the air felt gray. There might be a chance of more snow today. Halima wriggled into her silk shift and dress, making laughing jokes about how she would like to have a maid while Chesa was doing up the rows of buttons that ran down Egwene's back. The plump woman wore a set face, ignoring Halima altogether. Egwene said nothing.

ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ vɛɹi dətɝmənədli. hɑlimə wɑz nɑɾ əɹ sɝvənt. ʃi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə sɛt stændɝdz fəɹ ðə wʊmən. dʒʌst əz tʃɛsə fɪnɪʃt ðə læst ə ðə taɪni bʌɾənz ən ɡeɪv ɛɡwinz ɑɹm ə pæt, naɪsaʊ dʌkt ɪndə ðə tɛnt, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn ə fɹɛʃ weɪv ə koʊld ɛɹ. ðə bɹif ɡlɪmps əfɔɹɾəd bɪfɔɹ ðə flæps fɛl bɪhaɪn əɹ ʃoʊd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ɡɹeɪ aʊtsaɪd. dɛfənətli ə tʃæns ə snoʊ.

She said nothing very determinedly. Halima was not her servant. She had no right to set standards for the woman. Just as Chesa finished the last of the tiny buttons and gave Egwene's arm a pat, Nisao ducked into the tent, letting in a fresh wave of cold air. The brief glimpse afforded before the flaps fell behind her showed that it was still gray outside. Definitely a chance of snow.

"aɪ mʌst spik tə ðə mʌðɝ əloʊn," ʃi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ əz ɪf ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi fɛl ðə snoʊ. sətʃ ə fɝm toʊn wɑz ənjuʒəwəl fɹəm ðə smɔl wʊmən.

"I must speak to the Mother alone," she said, holding her cloak around her as if she already felt the snow. Such a firm tone was unusual from the small woman.

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd tə tʃɛsə, hu kɝtsid, bʌt stɪl kɑʃənd, "naʊ doʊn lɛt jəɹ bɹɛkfəst ɡɛt koʊld," ɑn əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. hɑlimə pɔzd, aɪɪŋ naɪsaʊ ən ɛɡwin boʊθ, bɪfɔɹ skupɪŋ ʌp əɹ kloʊk fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt leɪ ɪn ən əntaɪɾi hip ət ðə fʊɾ ə hɝ kɑt. "aɪ səpoʊz dɛlænə hæz wɝk fəɹ mi," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɪɹəteɪɾəd. naɪsaʊ fɹaʊn ət ðə wʊmənz bæk əz ʃi lɛft, bʌt wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ʃi ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ ən woʊv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ ən ɛɡwin. wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ pɝməs sən. "æneɪjə ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ ɑɹ dɛd," ʃi sɛd. "sʌm ə ðə wɝkmɪn bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn sæks ə koʊlz læs naɪt hɝɾ ə nɔɪz, laɪk sʌmwʌn θɹæʃɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ən fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ðeɪ ɔl wɛn ɹʌn nɪŋ tə si wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ðeɪ faʊn æneɪjə ən sɛɾɑɡænə laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ, dɛd." ɛɡwin sæt daʊn sloʊli ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt fil pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli kʌmftəɹbəl ət ðə moʊmənt.

Egwene nodded to Chesa, who curtsied, but still cautioned, "Now don't let your breakfast get cold," on her way out of the tent. Halima paused, eyeing Nisao and Egwene both, before scooping up her cloak from where it lay in an untidy heap at the foot of her cot. "I suppose Delana has work for me," she said, sounding irritated. Nisao frowned at the woman's back as she left, but without saying anything she embraced saidar and wove a ward against eavesdropping around her and Egwene. Without asking permis sion. "Anaiya and her Warder are dead," she said. "Some of the workmen bringing in sacks of coals last night heard a noise, like someone thrashing around, and for a wonder, they all went run ning to see what it was. They found Anaiya and Setagana lying in the snow, dead." Egwene sat down slowly on her chair, which did not feel particularly comfortable at the moment.

æneɪjə, dɛd. ʃi hæd hæd noʊ bjuɾi ɪksɛpt əɹ smaɪl, bʌt wən ʃi smaɪld, ɪt wɔɹmd ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. ə pleɪn-feɪst wʊmən u lʌv leɪs ɑn əɹ ɹoʊbz. ɛɡwin nu ʃi ʃəd fil sædnəs fəɹ sɛɾɑɡænə, tu, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ə wɔɹɾɝ. ɪf i hæd sɝvaɪvd æneɪjə, ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli hi wʊɾə lɪv lɔŋ. "haʊ?" ʃi sɛd. naɪsaʊ wəd nɑɾ əv woʊvən ðət wɔɹd dʒʌs tə tɛl əɹ æneɪjə wɑz dɛd.

Anaiya, dead. She had had no beauty except her smile, but when she smiled, it warmed everything around her. A plain-faced woman who loved lace on her robes. Egwene knew she should feel sadness for Setagana, too, but he had been a Warder. If he had survived Anaiya, it was unlikely he would have lived long. "How?" she said. Nisao would not have woven that ward just to tell her Anaiya was dead.

naɪsaʊz feɪs taɪɾənd, ən dɪspaɪt ðə wɔɹd, ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əz ɪf ʃi fɪɹd sʌmwʌn maɪt bi lɪsnɪŋ ət ði ɛntʃɹi flæps. "ðə wɝkmɪn θɔt ðeɪ hæɾ iɾən bædli pɹəzɝv mʌʃɹumz.

Nisao's face tightened, and despite the ward, she looked over her shoulder as if she feared someone might be listening at the entry flaps. "The workmen thought they had eaten badly preserved mushrooms.

səm fɑɹmɝz ɑɹ kɛɹləs ɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə sɛl, ən ðə ɹɔŋ sɔɹt kən pɛɹəlaɪz jəɹ lʌŋz əɹ meɪk jəɹ θɹoʊt swɛl ʌp, soʊ jə daɪ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ ɛɹ." ɛɡwin nɑɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli. ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp ɪn ə kʌntʃɹi vɪlədʒ, æftɝ ɔl. "ɛvɹiwʌn simd wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛp ðæt," naɪsaʊ wɛn ɑn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt hɝi. hænz twɪstɪŋ ən flɛksɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒəz ə hɝ kloʊk, ʃi əpɪɹd ɹɪlʌktən tə ɹitʃ əɹ kənkluʒən. "ðɛɹ wɝ noʊ wunz, noʊ ɪnʒɝiz ʌv ɛni sɔɹt. noʊ ɹizən tə θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ə ɡɹiɾi fɑɹmɝ sɛlɪŋ bæd mʌʃɹumz. bʌt. . . ." ʃi saɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əɡɛn, ən loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪt wɑz ɔl ðə tɔk ə ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪn ðə hɔl tədeɪ. aɪ tɛstəd fəɹ ɹɛzənəns. ðeɪ wɝ kɪld wɪð seɪɾɪn." ə ɡɹɪmɑs ə dɪsɡʌs kɹɔst əɹ feɪs. "aɪ θɪŋk sʌmwʌn dʒʌst woʊv sɑləd floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ən lɛɾ əm smʌðɝ." ʃʌɾɝɪŋ, ʃi dʒɹu hɝ kloʊk kloʊsɝ.

Some farmers are careless in gathering what they intend to sell, and the wrong sort can paralyze your lungs or make your throat swell up, so you die struggling for air." Egwene nodded impatiently. She had grown up in a country village, after all. "Everyone seemed willing to accept that," Nisao went on, but she did not hurry. Hands twisting and flexing on the edges of her cloak, she appeared reluctant to reach her conclusion. "There were no wounds, no injuries of any sort. No reason to think it was anything but a greedy farmer selling bad mushrooms. But. . . ." She sighed, glancing over her shoulder again, and lowered her voice. "I suppose it was all the talk of the Black Tower in the Hall today. I tested for resonance. They were killed with saidin." A grimace of disgust crossed her face. "I think someone just wove solid flows of Air around their heads and let them smother." Shuddering, she drew her cloak closer.

ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə ʃʌɾɝ, tu. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ʃi dɪd nɑt. æneɪjə, dɛd. smʌðɝd. ə dɪlɪbɝətli kɹuəl weɪ ʌv kɪlɪŋ, juz baɪ sʌmwʌn u hæd hoʊp tə liv noʊ tʃɹeɪsəz. "hæv jə toʊld ɛniwʌn, jɛt?"

Egwene wanted to shudder, too. She was surprised she did not. Anaiya, dead. Smothered. A deliberately cruel way of killing, used by someone who had hoped to leave no traces. "Have you told anyone, yet?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," naɪsaʊ sɛɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. "aɪ keɪm tə jə stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ. əz sun əz aɪ nu jud bi əweɪk, ət list." "ə pɪɾi. jəl əv tə ɪkspleɪn waɪ jə dɪleɪd. wi kæn kip ðɪs sikɹət." wɛl, æmɪɝlənz hæd kɛp dɑɹkɝ sikɹəts, fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ əz ðeɪ sɔ ɪt. "ɪf wɪv ə mæn u kən tʃænəl əmʌŋ ʌs, ðən ðə sɪstɝz nid tə bi ɑn ðɛɹ ɡɑɹd." ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl haɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə wɝkmɪn əɹ soʊlʒɝz simd ənlaɪkli, bʌt lɛs soʊ ðən wʌn kʌmɪŋ ðəɹ dʒʌs tə kɪl ə sɪŋɡəl sɪstɝ ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. wɪtʃ ɹeɪzd ənʌðɝ kwɛstʃən. "waɪ æneɪjə? wɑz ʃi dʒʌst ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ pleɪs ət ðə ɹɔŋ taɪm, naɪsaʊ? wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ daɪ?"

"Of course not," Nisao said indignantly. "I came to you straightaway. As soon as I knew you'd be awake, at least." "A pity. You will have to explain why you delayed. We can't keep this secret." Well, Amyrlins had kept darker secrets, for the good of the Tower as they saw it. "If we have a man who can channel among us, then the sisters need to be on their guard." A man who could channel hiding among the workmen or soldiers seemed unlikely, but less so than one coming there just to kill a single sister and her Warder. Which raised another question. "Why Anaiya? Was she just in the wrong place at the wrong time, Nisao? Where did they die?"

"nɪɹ ðə wæɡənz ɑn ðə saʊθ saɪɾ ə kæmp. aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ ðət taɪm ə naɪt. ənlɛs æneɪjə wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə pɹaɪviz ən sɛɾɑɡænə θɔt ʃi nid ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ivən ðɛɹ."

"Near the wagons on the south side of camp. I don't know why they were there that time of night. Unless Anaiya was going to the privies and Setagana thought she need guarding even there."

"ðɛn jəɹ gɑnə faɪn aʊt fəɹ mi, naɪsaʊ. wʌt wɝ æneɪjə ən sɛɾɑɡænə duɪŋ aʊt wən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls wɑz əslip? waɪ wɝ ðeɪ kɪld? ðɪs, jəl kip sikɹət. əntɪl jə kən ɡɪmi ɹizənz, noʊ wʌn bʌt ðə tu ʌv əs ɪz tə noʊ jəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ɛni." naɪsaʊz maʊθ oʊpən ən kloʊzd. "ɪf aɪ mʌst, aɪ mʌst," ʃi mʌɾɝd oʊnli hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

"Then you're going to find out for me, Nisao. What were Anaiya and Setagana doing out when everybody else was asleep? Why were they killed? This, you will keep secret. Until you can give me reasons, no one but the two of us is to know you're looking for any." Nisao's mouth opened and closed. "If I must, I must," she muttered only half under her breath.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹɪli suɾəd tə kipɪŋ dip sikɹəts, ən ʃi nu ɪt. ðə læst ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kip hæd lɛd dɝɛkli tə hɝ hævɪŋ tə swɛɹ fiəlti tə ɛɡwin. "wɪl ðɪs pʊɾ ə stɑp tə tɔk əbaʊɾ ən əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə blæk taʊɝ?" "aɪ daʊɾ ɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd wɛɹəli. laɪt, haʊ kəd ʃi bi wɪɹi ɔlɹɛɾi? ðə sʌn wɑz nɑt fʊli ʌp jɛt. "iðɝ weɪ, aɪ θɪŋk ɪts gɑnə bi ənʌðɝ vɛɹi lɔŋ deɪ." ən ðə bɛst ʃi kəd faɪn tə hoʊp fəɹ ɪn ɪt wɑz ðət ʃi kəd meɪk ɪt tə ənʌðɝ naɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə hɛdeɪk.

She was not really suited to keeping deep secrets, and she knew it. The last she had tried to keep had led directly to her having to swear fealty to Egwene. "Will this put a stop to talk about an agreement with the Black Tower?" "I doubt it," Egwene said wearily. Light, how could she be weary already? The sun was not fully up yet. "Either way, I think it is going to be another very long day." And the best she could find to hope for in it was that she could make it to another night without a headache.

tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn

CHAPTER 21

eɪ mɑɹk ɑlviɛɝɪn stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, lɛɾɪŋ ɪt snæp ʃʌt bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn ə feɪɾɪŋ slæʃ ə bɹɪljən blu-waɪt, ən ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli sniz fɹəm ðə dʌs kɪkt ʌp baɪ hɝ ʃuz. ət wʌns ənʌðɝ sniz ɹæk hɝ, ən ðən ənʌðɝ ðət bɹɔt tɪɹz tə hɝ aɪz. lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ðə ɡloʊɪŋ ɡloʊb ðət floʊɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ðə ɹʌf-wɔl stɔɹɹum hjun aʊɾ ə ðə bɛdʒɹɑk θɹi lɛvəlz bɪloʊ ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz wɝθ ə dʌst. ʃi wəd mʌtʃ ɹæðɝ əv ɹɪtɝn stʃɹeɪt tə hɝ əpɑɹtməns ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə tʃæns ʌv wɔkɪŋ ɪn tə faɪn ə sɝvən klinɪŋ, ən ðən ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə bɑɾi ən hoʊp ðət noʊ wʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ðə sɝvən hæd læs bɪn sin ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə hɝ ɹumz. ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən ən ɹaʊs nɑɾ ivən ðə slaɪɾəst hɪn ə səspɪʃən, mɛsænə hæd kəmændəd. ðət simd oʊvɝtɪməd wən ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæd wɔk ðə taʊɝ wɪð ɪmpjunɪɾi sɪns ɪts faʊndɪŋ, bʌt wən wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən kəmændəd, oʊnli ə ful dɪsoʊbeɪd. ət list, ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni tʃæns ə biɪŋ faʊn aʊt.

A Mark Alviarin stepped through the gateway, letting it snap shut behind her in a fading slash of brilliant blue-white, and almost immediately sneezed from the dust kicked up by her shoes. At once another sneeze racked her, and then another that brought tears to her eyes. Lit only by the glowing globe that floated in front of her, the rough-walled storeroom hewn out of the bedrock three levels below the Tower Library was empty except for centuries worth of dust. She would much rather have returned straight to her apartments in the Tower itself, but there was always the chance of walking in to find a servant cleaning, and then she would have to get rid of the body and hope that no one remembered that the servant had last been seen going into her rooms. Remain hidden and rouse not even the slightest hint of suspicion, Mesaana had commanded. That seemed overtimid when the Black Ajah had walked the Tower with impunity since its founding, but when one of the Chosen commanded, only a fool disobeyed. At least, if there was any chance of being found out.

ɪɹɪɾəbli, ɑlviɛɝɪn tʃænəl tə fɔɹs ðə dʌst aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ, slæmɪŋ ɪt daʊn soʊ hɑɹd ðət ðə stoʊn flɔɹ ʃəɾ əv ʃeɪkən. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə ɡoʊ θɹu ðɪs ɛvɹi taɪm ɪf ʃi sɪmpli swɛpt ɔl ðə dʌst ɪndə ə kɔɹnɝ ɹæðɝ ðən livɪŋ ɪt spɹɛɾ aʊt. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd kʌm ðɪs fɑɹ ɪndə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi beɪsməns ɪn jɪɹz; noʊ wʌn wəd noʊɾəs ðə ɹum wɑz klin. bʌt sʌmwʌn wɑz ɔlweɪz duɪŋ wʌt noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ dɪd. ʃi ɔfən dɪd soʊ hɝsɛlf, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə bi kɑt θɹu ə fulɪʃ mɪsteɪk.

Irritably, Alviarin channeled to force the dust out of the air, slamming it down so hard that the stone floor should have shaken. She would not have to go through this every time if she simply swept all the dust into a corner rather than leaving it spread out. No one else had come this far into the Library basements in years; no one would notice the room was clean. But someone was always doing what no one ever did. She often did so herself, and she did not intend to be caught through a foolish mistake.

stɪl, ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əz ʃi tʃænəl ðə ɹɛɾɪʃ mʌd fɹəm əɹ ʃuz ən ðə hɛm ə hɝ skɝts ən kloʊk. ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪɾ əz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, ðə lɑɹdʒəst ə ðə si foʊk aɪlənz, bʌt sʌmwʌn maɪt wʌndɝ wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn tə ɡɛt mʌɾi. ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz wəd bi bɛɹiɾ ɪn snoʊ ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ʃʌvəl klɪɹ ən ðə dɝt fɹoʊzən hɑɹd.

Still, she grumbled under her breath as she channeled the reddish mud from her shoes and the hem of her skirts and cloak. It seemed unlikely that anyone would recognize it as coming from Tremalking, the largest of the Sea Folk islands, but someone might wonder where she had been to get muddy. The Tower grounds would be buried in snow except where they had been shoveled clear and the dirt frozen hard.

stɪl mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, ʃi tʃænəld əɡɛn tə mʌfəl ðə skwil ə ɹʌstəd hɪnʒɪz əz ʃi pʊʃt oʊpən ðə ɹʌf wʊɾən dɔɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ tə meɪk ə wiv ən haɪɾ ɪt, soʊ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv tə sɑfən ðət kɹik ɛvɹi taɪm - ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ðəɹ wɑz - bʌt mɛsænə ɹəfjuz tə titʃ ɪt tə hɝ.

Still muttering to herself, she channeled again to muffle the squeal of rusted hinges as she pushed open the rough wooden door. There was a way to make a weave and hide it, so she would not have to soften that creak every time - she was certain there was - but Mesaana refused to teach it to her.

mɛsænə wɑz ðə ɹil sɔɹs ə hɝ ənɔɪəns. ðə tʃoʊzən tɔt wʌt ʃi wɪʃt ən nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ, hɪntəɾ ət wʌndɝz ðən wɪθhɛl ðɛm. ən mɛsænə juzd əɹ laɪk ən ɛɹənd ɡɝl. ʃi sæɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl ən nu ðə neɪmz ʌv ɛvɹi blæk sɪstɝ ɪn ɛvɹi hɑɹt, wɪtʃ wɑz mɔɹ ðən mɛsænə kəd seɪ. ðə wʊmən ʃoʊd lɪɾəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn u wəd kæɹi aʊɾ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ kæɹiɾ aʊt, ən tə ði æbsəlut lɛɾɝ. ɔl tu ɔfən, ʃi wɑntəɾ əm kæɹiɾ aʊt baɪ ɑlviɛɝɪn hɝsɛlf, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ tə dil wɪð wɪmən ən mɛn u θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz əɹ ikwəlz dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. tu mɛni ʌv ðə fɹɛnz θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz ikwəl tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ ivən supɪɹiɝ. wɝs, mɛsænə fɝbeɪɾ əɹ tə meɪk ən ɑbʒɛkt lɛsən ʌv ivən wʌn. ɹɪpɛlən lɪɾəl ɹoʊɾənts, nʌn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, ən ɑlviɛɝɪn hæd tə bi pəlaɪt dʒʌs kəz səm ə ðɛm maɪt bi sɝvɪŋ ənʌðɝ ə ðə tʃoʊzən! ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðət mɛsænə dɪd nɑt noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ. ʃi wɑz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ən ʃi meɪɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn smaɪl ət ðə dʌst ə ðə stʃɹit fəɹ əɹ ənsɝɾənti.

Mesaana was the real source of her annoyance. The Chosen taught what she wished and nothing more, hinted at wonders then withheld them. And Mesaana used her like an errand girl. She sat at the head of the Supreme Council and knew the names of every Black sister in every heart, which was more than Mesaana could say. The woman showed little interest in who would carry out her orders, so long as they were carried out, and to the absolute letter. All too often, she wanted them carried out by Alviarin herself, forcing her to deal with women and men who thought themselves her equals just because they also served the Great Lord. Too many of the Friends thought themselves equal to Aes Sedai, or even superior. Worse, Mesaana forbade her to make an object lesson of even one. Repellent little rodents, none able to channel, and Alviarin had to be polite just because some of them might be serving another of the Chosen! It was obvious that Mesaana did not know for sure. She was one of the Chosen, and she made Alviarin smile at the dust of the street for her uncertainty.

ðə bɔl ə peɪl laɪt floʊɾɪŋ əhɛɾ ə hɝ fəɹ ɪluməneɪʃən, ɑlviɛɝɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd daʊn ðə ɹʌf stoʊn kɔɹəɾɝ, smuðɪŋ ðə dʌs bɪhaɪnd wɪð fɛðɝi bɹʌʃɪz ʌv ɛɹ soʊ ɪt wəd sim ʌndɪstɝbd ən ɹɪhɝsɪŋ sɛvɹəl tʃɔɪs θɪŋz ʃi wəd laɪk tə seɪ tə mɛsænə. ʃi wəɾ æktʃəli  seɪ nʌn ə ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪtʃ oʊnli hoʊn əɹ ɪɹɪteɪʃən. kɹɪɾɪsaɪzɪŋ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən ɪn ivən ðə maɪldəs tɝmz wɑz ə ʃɔɹt pæθ tə peɪn, pɝhæps tə dɛθ. ɔlmoʊst ʃʊɹli boʊθ, ɪn tʃɹuθ. wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən, ɡɹɑvəl ən oʊbeɪ wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ tə sɝvaɪv, ən ðə fɝst wɑz əz ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz ðə sɛkənd. ðə pɹaɪz ʌv ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi wɑz wɝθ ə lɪɾəl ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ. wɪð ðæt, ʃi kəd ɡeɪn ɔl ðə paʊɝ ʃi wɪʃt, mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ɛni æmɪɝlɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ wildɪd. fɝst, ðoʊ, ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi tə sɝvaɪv.

The ball of pale light floating ahead of her for illumination, Alviarin glided down the rough stone corridor, smoothing the dust behind with feathery brushes of Air so it would seem undisturbed and rehearsing several choice things she would like to say to Mesaana. She would actually say none of them, of course, which only honed her irritation. Criticizing one of the Chosen in even the mildest terms was a short path to pain, perhaps to death. Almost surely both, in truth. With the Chosen, grovel and obey was the only way to survive, and the first was as important as the second. The prize of immortality was worth a little groveling. With that, she could gain all the power she wished, much more than any Amyrlin had ever wielded. First, though, it was necessary to survive.

wʌns ʃi ɹitʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə fɝst ɹæmp liɾɪŋ ʌpwɝd, ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɑðɝd haɪɾɪŋ əɹ tʃɹeɪsəz. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt nɪɹli soʊ mʌtʃ dʌs hɪɹ, ən ðət mɑɹk baɪ ðə wilz ə hændkɑɹts ən skʌfs fɹəm ʃuz; ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə feɪn fʊtpɹɪns wəd nɛvɝ bi noʊɾəst. ʃi stɪl wɔkt kwɪkli, ðoʊ.

Once she reached the top of the first ramp leading upward, she no longer bothered hiding her traces. There was not nearly so much dust here, and that marked by the wheels of handcarts and scuffs from shoes; another set of faint footprints would never be noticed. She still walked quickly, though.

juʒəwəli, ðə θɔɾ ə lɪvɪŋ fɝɛvɝ bɹaɪɾənd hɝ, ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɪvɛntʃəwəli wildɪŋ paʊɝ θɹu mɛsænə əz ʃi naʊ dɪd θɹu ɪleɪɾə. wɛl, ɔlmoʊs ðə seɪm; ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ mɛsænə tə ɪleɪɾəz steɪɾ ə kəmplaɪəns wɑz tu æmbɪʃəs, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl taɪ stʃɹɪŋz tə ðə wʊmən ðət wəɾ əʃʊɹ əɹ oʊn ɹaɪz. tədeɪ, hɝ maɪn kɛpt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə fæk ðət ʃi hæd bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ fəɹ ɔlmoʊst ə mʌnθ. mɛsænə wəd nɑɾ əv bɑðɝd tə kip ɪleɪɾə ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl dʊɹɪŋ əɹ æbsəns, ðoʊ ðə tʃoʊzən wəd ʃʊɹli leɪ ðə fɔlt əɾ ɑlviɛɝɪnz fiɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ hæd ɡɔn əmɪs. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪleɪɾə wɑz pɹɑpɝli kaʊɾ æftɝ ðə læs taɪm. ðə wʊmən hæd bɛɡd fəɹ ɹilis fɹəm teɪkɪŋ pɹaɪvət pɛnənsɪz fɹəm ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. ʌv kɔɹs ʃi wɑz tu kaʊd tə hæv stɛpt aʊɾ ə laɪn. ʌv kɔɹs.

Usually, the thought of living forever brightened her, the thought of eventually wielding power through Mesaana as she now did through Elaida. Well, almost the same; expecting to bring Mesaana to Elaida's state of compliance was too ambitious, but she could still tie strings to the woman that would assure her own rise. Today, her mind kept returning to the fact that she had been out of the Tower for almost a month. Mesaana would not have bothered to keep Elaida under control during her absence, though the Chosen would surely lay the fault at Alviarin's feet if anything had gone amiss. Of course, Elaida was properly cowed after the last time. The woman had begged for release from taking private penances from the Mistress of Novices. Of course she was too cowed to have stepped out of line. Of course.

ɑlviɛɝɪn pʊʃt ɪleɪɾə fɝmli tə ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt sloʊ hɝ stɛps.

Alviarin pushed Elaida firmly to the back of her head, but she did not slow her steps.

ə sɛkən ɹæmp tʊk əɹ tə ðə haɪəs beɪsmənt, wɛɹ ʃi lɛt ðə ɡloʊɪŋ bɔl vænɪʃ ən ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ. ðə ʃædoʊz hɪɹ wɝ dɑɾəd wɪð pulz ʌv wɑn laɪt ðət nɪɹli tʌtʃt wʌn ənʌðɝ, kæs baɪ læmps sɪɾɪŋ ɪn aɪɝn bɹækəts əlɔŋ stoʊn wɔlz ðət wɝ nitli dʒɹɛst ɑn ðɪs lɛvəl. nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɹæt ðət wɛn skʌɾəlɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ə feɪn klɪk ə klɔz ɑn ðə flɔɹstoʊnz.

A second ramp took her to the highest basement, where she let the glowing ball vanish and released saidar. The shadows here were dotted with pools of wan light that nearly touched one another, cast by lamps sitting in iron brackets along stone walls that were neatly dressed on this level. Nothing moved except for a rat that went scuttling away with a faint click of claws on the floorstones.

ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ əɹ smaɪl. ɔlmoʊst. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz aɪz ɹɪɾəld ðə taʊɝ, naʊ, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn sim tə hæv noʊɾəst ðət ðə wɔɹɾɪŋz hæd feɪld. ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɛniθɪŋ mɛsænə hæd dʌn; ðə wɔɹdz sɪmpli noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝkt əz ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə. ðəɹ wɝ . . . ɡæps. ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ði ænəməl sɔ hɝ, əɹ ɹipɔɹɾəd wʌɾ ɪt hæd sin, bʌt ʃi stɪl dʌkt kwɪkli ɪndə ə nɛɹoʊ sɝkjəlɝ stɛɹkeɪs. ðəɹ maɪt bi pipəl əbaʊɾ ɑn ðɪs lɛvəl, ən pipəl wɝ nɑt tə bi tʃɹʌstɪd ðə seɪm əz ɹæts.

That almost made her smile. Almost. The Great Lord's eyes riddled the Tower, now, though no one seemed to have noticed that the wardings had failed. She did not think it was anything Mesaana had done; the wards simply no longer worked as they were supposed to. There were . . . gaps. She certainly did not care whether the animal saw her, or reported what it had seen, but she still ducked quickly into a narrow circular staircase. There might be people about on this level, and people were not to be trusted the same as rats.

pɝhæps, ʃi θɔɾ əz ʃi klaɪmd, ʃi kəd pɹoʊb mɛsænə əbaʊt ðəɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl flɛɹ ɪn ðə paʊɝ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi wɑz . . . dɛləkət. ðə tʃoʊzən wəd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz haɪɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪt. ɛvɹi wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl ɪn ðə hoʊl wɝl hæd tə bi wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt hæd hæpənd. ʃi wəd dʒʌst əv tə bi kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛt slɪp ɛniθɪŋ ðət sədʒɛstəd ðət ʃi hæɾ æktʃəli  vɪzəɾəd ðə saɪt. lɔŋ æftɝ ðə flɛɹ vænɪʃt, ʌv kɔɹs - ʃi wɑz nɑt stupəɾ ɪnʌf tə sɪmpli stʃɹoʊl ɪndə ðæt!  - bʌt mɛsænə sim tə θɪŋk ɑlviɛɝɪn ʃəd kæɹi aʊɾ əɹ tʃɔɹz wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ə moʊmən fəɹ hɝsɛlf. kəd ðə wʊmən ɹɪli bɪliv ðət ʃi hæd noʊ əfɛɹz ə hɝ oʊn tə si tə? ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bɪheɪv əz ɪf ʃi dɪɾ əv nʌn. fəɹ ðə moʊmən ɪt wɑz, ət list. ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, ʃi stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə smɔl pleɪn dɔɹ, ɹʌfli fɪnɪʃt ɑn ðɪs saɪd, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə teɪk hoʊld ə hɝsɛlf əz ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ kloʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹm. mɛsænə wɑz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, bʌt stɪl hjumən. mɛsænə meɪd mɪsteɪks. ən ʃi wəd kɪl ɑlviɛɝɪn ɪn ə hɑɹtbiɾ ɪf ʃi meɪd wʌn. ɡɹɑvəl, oʊbeɪ ən sɝvaɪv. ən ɔlweɪz bi wɛɹi. ʃi hæd noʊn ðət lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ miɾɪŋ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. ɹitʃɹivɪŋ ðə waɪt kipɝz stoʊl fɹəm əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ, ʃi sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ən kɹæk ðə dɔɹ kɛɹfəli tə lɪsən. saɪləns, əz ɪkspɛktəd. ʃi stɛpt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə naɪnθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi ən kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Perhaps, she thought as she climbed, she could probe Mesaana about that impossible flare in the Power, so long as she was . . . delicate. The Chosen would think she was hiding something if she never mentioned it. Every woman who could channel in the whole world had to be wondering what had happened. She would just have to be careful not to let slip anything that suggested that she had actually visited the site. Long after the flare vanished, of course - she was not stupid enough to simply stroll into that!  - but Mesaana seemed to think Alviarin should carry out her chores without taking a moment for herself. Could the woman really believe that she had no affairs of her own to see to? It was best to behave as if she did have none. For the moment it was, at least. In the shadows at the top of the stairs, she stopped in front of the small plain door, roughly finished on this side, in order to take hold of herself as she folded her cloak over her arm. Mesaana was one of the Chosen, but still human. Mesaana made mistakes. And she would kill Alviarin in a heartbeat if she made one. Grovel, obey and survive. And always be wary. She had known that long before meeting one of the Chosen. Retrieving the white Keeper's stole from her belt pouch, she settled it around her neck and cracked the door carefully to listen. Silence, as expected. She stepped out into the Ninth Depository and closed the door behind her.

ɑn ði ɪnɝ saɪd, ðə dɔɹ wɑz noʊ lɛs pleɪn, bʌt pɑlɪʃt tə ə sɑft ɡloʊ.

On the inner side, the door was no less plain, but polished to a soft glow.

ðə taʊɝ laɪbɹɛɹi wɑz dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə twɛlv dəpɑzətɔɹiz, ət list ɪnsəfɑɹ əz ðə wɝl nu, ən ðə naɪnθ wɑz ðə smɔləst, ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə tɛksts ɑn vɛɹiəs fɔɹmz ʌv ɛɹɪθmɛɾɪk, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə lɑɹdʒ tʃeɪmbɝ, ə lɔŋ oʊvəl wɪð ə flæɾənd doʊm fəɹ ə silɪŋ, fɪld wɪð ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ ʌv tɔl wʊɾən ʃɛlvz, itʃ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə nɛɹoʊ wɔkweɪ fɔɹ peɪsɪz əbʌv ðə sɛvən-kʌlɝd flɔɹ taɪlz. tɔl læɾɝz stʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ʃɛlvz, ɑn wilz soʊ ðeɪ kəd bi muvd izəli, boʊθ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən ɑn ðə wɔkweɪz, ən mɪɹɝd bɹæs stænd-læmps wɪð beɪsəz soʊ hɛvi ðəɾ itʃ tʊk θɹi əɹ fɔɹ mɛn tə muv. faɪɝ wɑz ə kɑnstən kənsɝn ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi. ðə stænd-læmps ɔl bɝn bɹaɪtli, ɹɛɾi tə laɪt ðə weɪ fəɹ ɛni sɪstɝ u wɑntəd tə faɪn ə bʊk əɹ bɑks mænjəskɹɪpt, bʌɾ ə ʃɛlv hændkɑɹt hoʊldɪŋ θɹi lɑɹdʒ lɛðɝ-keɪs vɑljumz tə bi ɹipleɪst wɑz stɪl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wʌn aɪl ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt fɹəm ðə læs taɪm ʃi wɔk θɹu. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni nid fəɹ dɪfɹən fɔɹmz ʌv ɛɹɪθmɛɾɪk əɹ waɪ soʊ mɛni bʊks hæd bɪn ɹɪɾən ɑn ðɛm, ən fəɹ ɔl ðə taʊɝ pɹaɪɾɪd ɪtsɛlf ɑn hævɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst kəlɛkʃən ə bʊks ɪn ðə wɝld, kʌvɝɪŋ ɛvɹi pɑsəbəl tɑpɪk, ɪt sim ðət moʊst ɛɛs sədaɪ əɡɹid wɪð hɝ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ ɪn ðə naɪnθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi, ðə ɹizən ʃi juzd ɪt fəɹ əɹ ɛntʃɹɪweɪ. ət ðə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz, stændɪŋ ɪnvaɪɾɪŋli oʊpən, ʃi lɪsən əntɪl ʃi wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd ðət ðə kɔɹəɾɝ bɪɑnd wɑz ɛmpti bɪfɔɹ slɪpɪŋ aʊt. ɛniwʌn wʊɾə θɔɾ ɪt stʃɹeɪnʒ ðət ʃi hæd dɪvɛləpt ən ɪntʃɹəs fəɹ ðə bʊks ɪn ðɛɹ.

The Tower Library was divided into twelve depositories, at least insofar as the world knew, and the Ninth was the smallest, given over to texts on various forms of arithmetic, yet it was still a large chamber, a long oval with a flattened dome for a ceiling, filled with row on row of tall wooden shelves, each surrounded by a narrow walkway four paces above the seven-colored floor tiles. Tall ladders stood alongside the shelves, on wheels so they could be moved easily, both on the floor and on the walkways, and mirrored brass stand-lamps with bases so heavy that each took three or four men to move. Fire was a constant concern in the Library. The stand-lamps all burned brightly, ready to light the way for any sister who wanted to find a book or boxed manuscript, but a shelved handcart holding three large leather-cased volumes to be replaced was still in the middle of one aisle exactly where she remembered it from the last time she walked through. She did not understand why there was any need for different forms of arithmetic or why so many books had been written on them, and for all the Tower prided itself on having the greatest collection of books in the world, covering every possible topic, it seemed that most Aes Sedai agreed with her. She had never seen another sister in the Ninth Depository, the reason she used it for her entryway. At the wide arched doors, standing invitingly open, she listened until she was satisfied that the corridor beyond was empty before slipping out. Anyone would have thought it strange that she had developed an interest for the books in there.

əz ʃi hɝiɾ əlɔŋ ðə meɪn kɔɹɪɾɝz, wɛɹ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz wɝ leɪɾ ɪn ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ɹoʊz ə ði ədʒɑ kʌlɝz, ɪt keɪm tə hɝ ðət ðə laɪbɹɛɹi wɑz mɔɹ saɪlən ðən juʒəwəl, ivən kaʊntɪŋ haʊ fju ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ ət pɹɛzənt. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə sɪstɝ əɹ tu tə bi sin, ɪf oʊnli ðə laɪbɹɛɹiənz - səm bɹaʊnz æktʃəli  meɪnteɪn əpɑɹtməns ɪn ði ʌpɝ lɛvəlz ɪn ədɪʃən tə ðɛɹ ɹumz ɪn ðə taʊɝ - jɛt ðə hjudʒ fɪɡjɝz kɑɹvd ɪndə ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz' wɔlz, fænsɪfəli ɡɑɹb pipəl ən stʃɹeɪnʒ ænəməlz tɛn fit tɔl əɹ mɔɹ, maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹiz oʊnli ɪnhæbəɾənts. dʒɹæfs meɪd ði ɪntʃɹəkətli kɑɹv læmp wilz hæŋɪŋ tɛn peɪsɪz oʊvɝhɛd kɹik feɪnli ɑn ðɛɹ tʃeɪnz. hɝ fʊtstɛps simd ənnətʃɝəli laʊd, kæstɪŋ sɑft ɛkoʊz fɹəm ðə vɔltəd silɪŋ. "meɪ aɪ hɛlp ju?" ə wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd kwaɪətli bɪhaɪn hɝ. stɑɹɾəld, ɑlviɛɝɪn spʌn ɝaʊnd, ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ kloʊk, bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kætʃ hɝsɛlf. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə wɔk θɹu ðə laɪbɹɛɹi, zəmɛl," ʃi sɛd, ən ɪmiɾiətli fɛlt ə stæb ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən. ɪf ʃi wɑz dʒʌmpi ɪnʌf tə ɪkspleɪn hɝsɛlf tə ə laɪbɹɛɹiən, ðən ʃi ɹɪli dɪd nid tə teɪk ə ɡɹɪp bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹipɔɹɾəd tə mɛsænə. ʃi ɔlmoʊst wɑntəd tə tɛl zəmɛl wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, dʒʌs tə si wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən wəd flɪntʃ.

As she hurried along the main corridors, where the floor tiles were laid in repeating rows of the Ajah colors, it came to her that the Library was more silent than usual, even counting how few Aes Sedai remained in the Tower at present. There was always a sister or two to be seen, if only the librarians - some Browns actually maintained apartments in the upper levels in addition to their rooms in the Tower - yet the huge figures carved into the corridors' walls, fancifully garbed people and strange animals ten feet tall or more, might have been the Library's only inhabitants. Drafts made the intricately carved lamp wheels hanging ten paces overhead creak faintly on their chains. Her footsteps seemed unnaturally loud, casting soft echoes from the vaulted ceiling. "May I help you?" a woman's voice said quietly behind her. Startled, Alviarin spun around, almost dropping her cloak, before she could catch herself. "I just wanted to walk through the Library, Zemaille," she said, and immediately felt a stab of irritation. If she was jumpy enough to explain herself to a librarian, then she really did need to take a grip before she reported to Mesaana. She almost wanted to tell Zemaille what was happening on Tremalking, just to see whether the woman would flinch.

ðə blæn ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz dɑɹk feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ ə tʌtʃ ə səm ənɹiɾəbəl ɪmoʊʃən ɔltɝd ðə pɪtʃ ə hɝ vɔɪs. tɔl ən vɛɹi lin, zəmɛl ɔlweɪz hɛl ðəɾ aʊɾɝ mæsk ə ɹɪzɝv ən dɪstəns, bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz lɛs ʃaɪ ðən ʃi pɹitɛndəd, ən lɛs plɛzənt. "ðæts kwaɪɾ ʌndɝstændəbəl. ðə laɪbɹɛɹi ɪz ɹɛsfəl, ən ɪts ə sæd taɪm fəɹ əs ɔl. ən sæɾɝ stɪl fəɹ ju, ʌv kɔɹs."

The bland expression on the Brown sister's dark face did not change, but a touch of some unreadable emotion altered the pitch of her voice. Tall and very lean, Zemaille always held that outer mask of reserve and distance, but Alviarin suspected she was less shy than she pretended, and less pleasant. "That's quite understandable. The Library is restful, and it's a sad time for us all. And sadder still for you, of course."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd əz ɪf baɪ ɹoʊt. ə sæd taɪm? fəɹ əɹ ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ? ʃi kənsɪɾɝd dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə wʊmən tə səm sɪkluɾɪd kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ ʃi kəd bi kwɛstʃən ən dɪspoʊzd ʌv, bʌt ðən ʃi noʊɾəst ənʌðɝ bɹaʊn, ə ɹaʊnd wʊmən ivən dɑɹkɝ ðən zəmɛl, wɑtʃɪŋ əm fɹəm fɑɹðɝ daʊn ðə hɔl. eɪɾən ən zəmɛl wɝ wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ, jɛɾ oʊvɝkʌmɪŋ boʊθ ət wʌns wəd bi dɪfəkəlt ɪf ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl əɾ ɔl. waɪ wɝ ðeɪ boʊθ daʊn hɪɹ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ? ðə pɛɹ wɑz sɛldəm sin, ʃʌɾəlɪŋ bɪtwin ðə ɹumz ɑn ði ʌpɝ lɛvəlz ðeɪ ʃɛɹd wɪð naɪaɪn, ðə θɝd si foʊk sɪstɝ, ən ðə soʊ-kɔl θɝtinθ dɪpɑzətɔɹi, wɛɹ ðə sikɹət ɹɛkɝdz wɝ kɛpt. ɔl θɹi wɝk ðɛɹ, wɪlɪŋli ɪmɝs tə ðɛɹ nɛks ɪn ðɛɹ leɪbɝz. ʃi wɔkt ɑn ən tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɝsɛlf ʃi wɑz biɪŋ skɪɾɪʃ wɪθaʊt ɹizən, bʌt ðət dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə suð ðə pɹɪklɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz.

"Of course," Alviarin repeated as if by rote. A sad time? For her in particular? She considered drawing the woman to some secluded corner where she could be questioned and disposed of, but then she noticed another Brown, a round woman even darker than Zemaille, watching them from farther down the hall. Aiden and Zemaille were weak in the Power, yet overcoming both at once would be difficult if it was possible at all. Why were they both down here on the ground floor? The pair was seldom seen, shuttling between the rooms on the upper levels they shared with Nyein, the third Sea Folk sister, and the so-called Thirteenth Depository, where the secret records were kept. All three worked there, willingly immersed to their necks in their labors. She walked on and tried to tell herself she was being skittish without reason, but that did nothing to soothe the prickling between her shoulder blades.

ðə læk ə laɪbɹɛɹiənz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə fɹʌn ɛntʃɹəns oʊnli meɪd ðə pɹɪkəlz ɡɹoʊ. laɪbɹɛɹiənz ɔlweɪz stʊɾ əɾ ɛvɹi ɛntʃɹəns, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ nɑɾ ə skɹæp ə peɪpɝ lɛf ðə laɪbɹɛɹi wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ nɑlədʒ.

The lack of librarians guarding the front entrance only made the prickles grow. Librarians always stood at every entrance, to make sure not a scrap of paper left the library without their knowledge.

ɑlviɛɝɪn tʃænəl tə ʃʌv wʌn ə ðə tɔl kɑɹv dɔɹz oʊpən bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ɪɾ ən lɛft ɪt stændɪŋ əɡeɪp ɑn ɪts bɹɑnz hɪnʒɪz əz ʃi hɝid daʊn ðə waɪd mɑɹbəl stɛɹz. ðə bɹɔd, oʊk-laɪn stoʊn pæθ ðət lɛd təwɔɹd ðə tɔl waɪt ʃæft ə ðə taʊɝ hæd bɪn ʃʌvəl klɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪf ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn, ʃi wʊɾə juz ðə paʊɝ tə mɛl ðə snoʊ əweɪ əhɛɾ ə hɝ, lɛɾ ɛniwʌn θɪŋk ʌv ɪt wʌt ðeɪ wʊd.

Alviarin channeled to shove one of the tall carved doors open before she reached it and left it standing agape on its bronze hinges as she hurried down the wide marble stairs. The broad, oak-lined stone path that led toward the tall white shaft of the Tower had been shoveled clear, but if it had not been, she would have used the Power to melt the snow away ahead of her, let anyone think of it what they would.

mɛsænə hæd meɪd kɹɪstəl klɪɹ ðə pɹaɪs ə teɪkɪŋ ðə ɹɪsk ðəɾ ɛniwʌn maɪt lɝn ðə wiv fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, əɹ ivən ðət ʃi nu ɪt, ɛls ʃi wʊɾə tʃɹævəl fɹəm ðə spɑt. wɪð ðə taʊɝ ɪn saɪt, lumɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹiz ən ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə peɪl mɔɹnɪŋ sʌnlaɪt, ʃi cʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ ɪn ə stɛp. ɪnstɛd, ʃi fɔt ði ɝdʒ tə ɹʌn.

Mesaana had made crystal clear the price of taking the risk that anyone might learn the weave for Traveling, or even that she knew it, else she would have Traveled from the spot. With the Tower in sight, looming over the trees and gleaming in the pale morning sunlight, she could have been there in a step. Instead, she fought the urge to run.

ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðə taʊɝz waɪd, tɔl kɔɹɪɾɝz* eɪ mɑɹk faɪvhʌnʒɹədfaɪv ɛmpti. ə fju skɝiɪŋ sɝvəns wɪð ðə waɪt fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɑn ðɛɹ bɹɛsts bɑb ðɛɹ baʊz ən kɝtsiz əz ʃi pæst, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ juz, noʊ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðən ðə dʒɹæfs ðət meɪd ðə ɡɪldɪd stænd-læmps nɪkɝ ən ɹɪpəl ðə bɹaɪt tæpəstʃɹiz hæŋɪŋ ɑn ðə snoʊi waɪt wɔlz. sɪstɝz kɛp tə ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒɑ kɔɹɾɝz əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl ðiz deɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ənlɛs ʃi ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ə mɛmbɝ ə hɝ oʊn hɑɹt, ivən siɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi nu wɑz blæk ədʒɑ wʊɾə bɪn jusləs. ʃi nu ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɹɪvil hɝsɛlf tə ɛniwʌn ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə.

It was no surprise to find the Tower's wide, tall corridors* A MARK 505 empty. A few scurrying servants with the white Flame of Tar Valon on their breasts bobbed their bows and curtsies as she passed, but they were no more use, no more important, than the drafts that made the gilded stand-lamps nicker and rippled the bright tapestries hanging on the snowy white walls. Sisters kept to their own Ajah quarters as much as possible these days, of course, and unless she encountered a member of her own heart, even seeing an Aes Sedai she knew was Black Ajah would have been useless. She knew them, but they did not know her. Besides, she was not about to reveal herself to anyone she did not have to.

pɝhæps səm ə ðoʊz mɑɹvələs ɪnstʃɹəməns fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðət mɛsænə tɔkt əbaʊt wəɾ əlaʊ hɝ tə kwɛstʃən ɛni sɪstɝ ɪmiɾiətli wʌn deɪ, ɪf ðə wʊmən ɛvɝ æktʃəli  pɹədus ðɛm, bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə mæɾɝ ə sɪfɝɾ ɔɹɾɝz lɛft ɑn pɪloʊz əɹ ɪn sikɹət spɑts. wʌt hæd wʌns simd ɔlmoʊst ɪnstəntæniəs ɹɪspɑnsɪz naʊ simd ɪntɝmɪnæbli dɪleɪd. ə stɑki bɔld-hɛɾəd sɝvɪŋ mæn meɪkɪŋ ɪz baʊ ɡʌlpt ɑɾəbli, ən ʃi smuðd əɹ fitʃɝz. ʃi pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn əɹ aɪsi dɪtætʃmənt, ɔlweɪz pɹɪzɛntɪŋ ə kul ənɹʌfəl sɝfəs. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, skaʊlɪŋ əɹ weɪ ðoʊ ðə taʊɝ gɑnə tə ɡɛɾ əɹ ɪɡzækli noʊwɛɹ.

Perhaps some of those marvelous instruments from the Age of Legends that Mesaana talked about would allow her to question any sister immediately one day, if the woman ever actually produced them, but now it was still a matter of ciphered orders left on pillows or in secret spots. What had once seemed almost instantaneous responses now seemed interminably delayed. A stocky bald-headed serving man making his bow gulped audibly, and she smoothed her features. She prided herself on her icy detachment, always presenting a cool unruffled surface. In any event, scowling her way though the Tower was going to get her exactly nowhere.

ðəɹ wɑz wʌn pɝsən ɪn ðə taʊɝ ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ tə faɪnd, sʌmwʌn ʃi kəd dɪmæn ænsɝz fɹəm wɪð noʊ fɪɹ ʌv wʌt ðə wʊmən θɔt. ə lɪɾəl kɑʃən wɑz niɾəd ivən ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs - kɛɹləs kwɛstʃənz ɹɪvil mɔɹ ðən moʊst ænsɝz wɝ wɝθ - bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə wəd tɛl əɹ ɛniθɪŋ. wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi bɪɡæn tə klaɪm.

There was one person in the Tower she was sure she knew exactly where to find, someone she could demand answers from with no fear of what the woman thought. A little caution was needed even there, of course - careless questions revealed more than most answers were worth - but Elaida would tell her anything. With a sigh, she began to climb.

mɛsænə hæd toʊld əɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ mɑɹvəl ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ðət ʃi wɪʃt vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə si, ə θɪŋ kɔld ə "lɪft." ðə flaɪɪŋ məʃinz saʊndəd mʌtʃ ɡɹændɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz fɑɹ iziɝ tə ɛnvɪʒən ə məkænɪkəl kəntʃɹaɪvəns ðət wɪsk jə fɹəm flɔɹ tə flɔɹ. ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹɪli sɝɾən ðət bɪldɪŋz sɛvɹəl taɪmz əz haɪ əz ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəd ɹɪli hæv ɪɡzɪstəd, iðɝ - ɪn ðə hoʊl wɝld, nɑɾ ivən ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ ɹaɪvəl ðə taʊɝz haɪt - bʌt dʒʌs noʊɪŋ əbaʊt "lɪfs" meɪd klaɪmɪŋ ʌp spaɪɹəlɪŋ hɔlweɪz ən swipɪŋ flaɪts ə stɛɹz sim ləbɔɹiəs. ʃi dɪd pɔz ət ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, oʊnli θɹi lɛvəlz ʌp, bʌɾ əz ɪkspɛktəd, boʊθ ɹumz wɝ ɛmpti, ðə bɛɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəlz pɑlɪʃt tɪl ðeɪ ʃoʊn. ðə ɹumz ðɛmsɛlvz sim bɛɹ, wɪð noʊ wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz, noʊ ɔɹnəməns, nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl bʌt ðə teɪbəlz ən tʃɛɹz ən ənlɪt stænd-læmps. ɪleɪɾə ɹɛɹli keɪm daʊn fɹəm əɹ əpɑɹtməns nɪɹ ðə taʊɝz pik ɛnimɔɹ. ðət hæd simd æksɛptəbəl ət wʌn taɪm, sɪns ɪɾ aɪsəleɪɾəd ðə wʊmən ivən mɔɹ fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊɝ. fju sɪstɝz meɪd ðət klaɪm wɪlɪŋli. tədeɪ, ðoʊ, baɪ ðə taɪm ɑlviɛɝɪn hæd klaɪm kloʊz tə eɪɾi spænz, ʃi wɑz sɪɹiəsli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ meɪkɪŋ ɪleɪɾə muv bæk daʊn. ɪleɪɾəz weɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɑz ɛmpti, ʌv kɔɹs, ðoʊ ə foʊldɝ ə peɪpɝz sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl sɛd sʌmwʌn hæd bɪn ðɛɹ. siɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kənteɪnd, ən dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ ɪleɪɾə niɾəd tə bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ hævɪŋ ɪt, kəd weɪt, ðoʊ. ɑlviɛɝɪn tɔst əɹ kloʊk daʊn ɑn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ, nuli kɑɹvd wɪð ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən əweɪɾɪŋ ðə ɡɪldɝ, ðət lɛd dipɝ ɪndə ði əpɑɹtməns.

Mesaana had told her of another marvel of the Age of Legends that she wished very much to see, a thing called a "lift." The flying machines sounded much grander, of course, but it was far easier to envision a mechanical contrivance that whisked you from floor to floor. She was not really certain that buildings several times as high as the White Tower could really have existed, either - in the whole world, not even the Stone of Tear rivaled the Tower's height - but just knowing about "lifts" made climbing up spiraling hallways and sweeping flights of stairs seem laborious. She did pause at the Amyrlin's study, only three levels up, but as expected, both rooms were empty, the bare writing tables polished till they shone. The rooms themselves seemed bare, with no wall hangings, no ornaments, nothing at all but the tables and chairs and unlit stand-lamps. Elaida rarely came down from her apartments near the Tower's peak anymore. That had seemed acceptable at one time, since it isolated the woman even more from the rest of the Tower. Few sisters made that climb willingly. Today, though, by the time Alviarin had climbed close to eighty spans, she was seriously considering making Elaida move back down. Elaida's waiting room was empty, of course, though a folder of papers sitting atop the writing table said someone had been there. Seeing what they contained, and deciding whether Elaida needed to be punished for having it, could wait, though. Alviarin tossed her cloak down on the writing table and pushed open the door, newly carved with the Flame of Tar Valon and awaiting the gilder, that led deeper into the apartments.

ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə sɝdʒ ə ɹɪlif ʃi fɛlt ət siɪŋ ɪleɪɾə sɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə stɑɹkli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪpt - noʊ, sɪks-stʃɹaɪpt, naʊ - stoʊl ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ən ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn pɪkt aʊɾ ɪn munstoʊnz əmʌŋ ðə ɡoʊldwɝk ɑn ðə haɪ tʃɛɹbæk əbʌv əɹ hɛd. ə nɪɡəlɪŋ wɝi ðət ʃi hæd nɑt lɛt sɝfəs əntɪl naʊ hæd bɪn ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət ðə wʊmən wɑz dɛɾ ɪn səm ful æksəɾənt. ðət wʊɾə ɪkspleɪn zəmɛlz kɑmɛnt. tʃuzɪŋ ə nu æmɪɝlɪn cʊɾə teɪkən mʌnθs, ivən wɪð ðə ɹɛbəlz ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls kənfɹʌntɪŋ ðɛm, bʌɾ əɹ deɪz əz kipɝ wʊɾə bɪn nʌmbɝd. wʌt sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ mɔɹ ðən əɹ ɹɪlif, ðoʊ, wɑz ðə pɹɛzəns ə mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə sɪɾɝz ɪn ðə hɔl stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ɪn ðɛɹ fɹɪnd ʃɔlz. ɪleɪɾə nu bɛɾɝ ðən tə ɛntɝteɪn ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə dɛləɡeɪʃən wɪθaʊɾ əɹ pɹizɛnt. ðə hjudʒ ɡɪldɪd keɪs klɑk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ə vʌlɡɑɹli oʊvɝ-ɔɹnəmɛntɪd pis, tʃaɪm twaɪs fəɹ haɪ, smɔl ɪnæməl fɪɡjɝz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ pɑpɪŋ aʊɾ ə taɪni dɔɹz ɪn ɪts fɹʌn əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə tɛl ðə sɪɾɝz ðət ʃi niɾəd tə kənfɝ wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn pɹaɪvətli. ðeɪ wəd liv wɪð lɪɾəl hɛmɪŋ əɹ hɔɪŋ. eɪ kipɝ hæd noʊ əθɔɹəɾi tə ɔɹɾɝ əm aʊt, bʌt ðeɪ nu ðəɾ əɹ əθɔɹəɾi ɪkstɛndəd bɪɑn ðəɾ əɹ stoʊl kənfɝɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə səspɛk haʊ ðət kəd bi.

She was surprised at the surge of relief she felt at seeing Elaida sitting behind the starkly carved and gilded writing table, the seven-striped - no, six-striped, now - stole around her neck and the Flame of Tar Valon picked out in moonstones among the goldwork on the high chairback above her head. A niggling worry that she had not let surface until now had been the possibility that the woman was dead in some fool accident. That would have explained Zemaille's comment. Choosing a new Amyrlin could have taken months, even with the rebels and everything else confronting them, but her days as Keeper would have been numbered. What surprised her more than her relief, though, was the presence of more than half the Sitters in the Hall standing in front of the writing table in their fringed shawls. Elaida knew better than to entertain this sort of delegation without her present. The huge gilded case clock against the wall, a vulgarly over-ornamented piece, chimed twice for High, small enameled figures of Aes Sedai popping out of tiny doors in its front as she opened her mouth to tell the Sitters that she needed to confer with the Amyrlin privately. They would leave with little hemming or hawing. A Keeper had no authority to order them out, but they knew that her authority extended beyond that her stole conferred even if they did not begin to suspect how that could be.

"ɑlviɛɝɪn," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, saʊndɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd, bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ ə wɝɾ aʊt. ðə hɑɹdnəs ʌv ɪleɪɾəz feɪs sɔfən ɪn wʌɾ ɔlmoʊst sim plɛʒɝ. hɝ maʊθ kwɝkt kloʊs tə ə smaɪl. ɪleɪɾə hæd hæd noʊ ɹizənz tə smaɪl ɪn səm taɪm. "stæn oʊvɝ ðəɹ ən bi kwaɪəɾ əntɪl aɪ hæv taɪm tə dil wɪð ju," ʃi sɛd, weɪvɪŋ ən ɪmpɪɹiəs hæn təwɔɹɾ ə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum. ðə sɪɾɝz ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ fiɾ ən ədʒʌstəd ðɛɹ ʃɔlz. swænə, ə bifi wʊmən, ɡeɪv ɑlviɛɝɪn ə taɪt ɡlæns, ən ʃɛvən, tɔl əz ə mæn ən æŋɡjəlɝ, stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ əɹ wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən, bʌt ði ʌðɝz əvɔɪɾəd miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪ.

"Alviarin," Elaida said, sounding surprised, before she could get a word out. The hardness of Elaida's face softened in what almost seemed pleasure. Her mouth quirked close to a smile. Elaida had had no reasons to smile in some time. "Stand over there and be quiet until I have time to deal with you," she said, waving an imperious hand toward a corner of the room. The Sitters shifted their feet and adjusted their shawls. Suana, a beefy woman, gave Alviarin a tight glance, and Shevan, tall as a man and angular, stared straight at her with no expression, but the others avoided meeting her eye.

stʌnd, ʃi stʊd stɑk-stɪl ɑn ðə bɹaɪtli pæɾɝnd sɪlk kɑɹpət, ɡeɪpɪŋ. ðɪs kəd nɑt bi mɪɹ ɹɪbɛljən ɑn ɪleɪɾəz pɑɹt - ðə wʊmən wəɾ əv tə bi ɪnseɪn! - bʌt wʌɾ ɪn ðə neɪm ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd hæpən tə ɡɪv əɹ ðə nɝv? wʌt? ɪleɪɾəz hæn slæp ðə teɪbəltɑp wɪð ə laʊd kɹæk, ə bloʊ ðət meɪd wʌn ə ðə lækɝd bɑksəz ðəɹ ɹæɾəl. "wɛn aɪ tɛl jə tə stæn ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, dɔɾɝ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ, deɪnʒɝəs vɔɪs, "aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə oʊbeɪ." hɝ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd. "ɔɹ ʃæl aɪ sʌmən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz soʊ ðiz sɪstɝz kən wɪtnəs jəɹ 'pɹaɪvət' pɛnəns?" hit səfjuzd ɑlviɛɝɪnz feɪs, pɑɹt hjumɪlieɪʃən ən pɑɹɾ æŋɡɝ. tə hæv ɛniwʌn hɪɹ sətʃ θɪŋz sɛd, ən tə hɝ feɪs! fɪɹ bʌbəld ɪn hɝ, tu, tɝnɪŋ əɹ stʌmək tə æsəd. ə fju wɝdz fɹəm hɝ, ən ɪleɪɾə wəd stæn əkjuzd ə sɛndɪŋ sɪstɝz tə dɪzæstɝ ən kæptɪvəɾi, nɑt wʌns bʌt twaɪs. ɹumɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡʌn swɝlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪvɛns ɪn kɛɹhin; mɝki ɹumɝz, bʌt ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ sɝɾən baɪ ðə deɪ.

Stunned, she stood stock-still on the brightly patterned silk carpet, gaping. This could not be mere rebellion on Elaida's part - the woman would have to be insane! - but what in the name of the Great Lord had happened to give her the nerve? What? Elaida's hand slapped the tabletop with a loud crack, a blow that made one of the lacquered boxes there rattle. "When I tell you to stand in the corner, Daughter," she said in a low, dangerous voice, "I expect you to obey." Her eyes glittered. "Or shall I summon the Mistress of Novices so these sisters can witness your 'private' penance?" Heat suffused Alviarin's face, part humiliation and part anger. To have anyone hear such things said, and to her face! Fear bubbled in her, too, turning her stomach to acid. A few words from her, and Elaida would stand accused of sending sisters to disaster and captivity, not once but twice. Rumors had already begun swirling about events in Cairhien; murky rumors, but growing more certain by the day.

ən wʌns ɪt wɑz lɝn ðəɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðæt, ɪleɪɾə hæd sɛn fɪfti sɪstɝz tə tʃɹaɪ tə dɪfit hʌnʒɹədz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, nɑɾ ivən ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə ðə ɹɛbəl sɪstɝz wɪntɝɪŋ ɪn mʊɹændi wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmi wəd kip ði æmɪɝlɪnz stoʊl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, əɹ əɹ hɛd. ʃi kəd nɑt dɛɹ tə də ðɪs. ənlɛs. . . .

And once it was learned that on top of that, Elaida had sent fifty sisters to try to defeat hundreds of men who could channel, not even the existence of the rebel sisters wintering in Murandy with their army would keep the Amyrlin's stole on her shoulders, or her head. She could not dare to do this. Unless. . . .

ənlɛs ʃi kəd dɪskɹɛɾət ɑlviɛɝɪn əz blæk ədʒɑ. ðət maɪt ɡeɪn əɹ ə lɪɾəl taɪm. oʊnli ə lɪɾəl, ʃʊɹli, wʌns ðə fæks əbaʊt dəməaɪz wɛlz ən ðə blæk taʊɝ wɝ noʊn, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə maɪt bi ɹɛɾi tə ɡɹæsp ət stʃɹɔz. noʊ, ɪt wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl, kəd nɑt bi pɑsəbəl.

Unless she could discredit Alviarin as Black Ajah. That might gain her a little time. Only a little, surely, once the facts about Dumai's Wells and the Black Tower were known, but Elaida might be ready to grasp at straws. No, it was not possible, could not be possible.

flaɪt sɝɾənli wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɪf ɪleɪɾə wɑz ɹɛɾi tə leɪ tʃɑɹdʒəz, flaɪt wəɾ oʊnli kənfɝm ðɛm. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, mɛsænə wəd faɪn əɹ ən kɪl əɹ ɪf ʃi flɛd. ɔl ðət flæʃt θɹu hɝ hɛɾ əz ʃi muvd ɑn lɛɾən fit tə stæn ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ laɪk ə pɛnɪɾɪnt nɑvəs. ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm ðɪs, wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpənd. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə weɪ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ. lɪsnɪŋ maɪt faɪn ɪt fəɹ hɝ. ʃi wəɾ əv pɹeɪd, ɪf ðə dɑɹk lɔɹd lɪsən tə pɹɛɹz.

Flight certainly was impossible. For one thing, if Elaida was ready to lay charges, flight would only confirm them. For another, Mesaana would find her and kill her if she fled. All that flashed through her head as she moved on leaden feet to stand in the corner like a penitent novice. There had to be a way to recover from this, whatever had happened. There was always a way to recover. Listening might find it for her. She would have prayed, if the Dark Lord listened to prayers.

ɪleɪɾə stʌɾid əɹ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɡeɪv ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. ðə wʊmənz aɪz stɪl ʃoʊn wɪð ɪmoʊʃən, ðoʊ. lɪftɪŋ ðə lɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə θɹi lækɝd bɑksəz ɑn əɹ teɪbəl, ʃi tʊk aʊɾ ə smɔl, eɪdʒ-dɑɹkən aɪvɝi kɑɹvɪŋ ʌv ə tɝɾəl ən stʃɹoʊkt ɪt bɪtwin əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. fɑndəlɪŋ ðə kɑɹvɪŋz ɪn ðət bɑks wɑz ə hæbət ʃi hæd wən ʃi wɑntəd tə suð əɹ nɝvz. "naʊ," ʃi sɛd. "ju wɝ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ tə mi waɪ aɪ ʃəɾ ɛntɝ nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz." "wi wɝ nɑɾ æskɪŋ pɝmɪʃən, mʌðɝ," swænə sɛd ʃɑɹpli, θɹʌstɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn aʊt. ʃi hæd tu mʌtʃ tʃɪn, ə skwɛɹ stoʊn ʌv ɪt, ən ði ɛɹəɡəns tə θɹʌst ɪɾ əɾ ɛniwʌn. "ə dɪsɪʒən ə ðɪs sɔɹt bɪlɔŋz tə ðə hɔl. ðəɹ ɪz stʃɹɔŋ filɪŋ ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ." wɪtʃ mɛnt ʃi hæd stʃɹɔŋ filɪŋz. ʃi wɑz ðə hɛɾ ə ðə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ðə fɝst wivɝ, sʌmθɪŋ ɑlviɛɝɪn nu kəz ðə blæk ədʒɑ nu ɔl ði ədʒɑ sikɹəts, əɹ nɪɹli ɔl, ən ɪn swænəz vju, hɝ əpɪnjənz wɝ əɹ ədʒɑz əpɪnjənz. dʌsin, ði ʌðɝ jɛloʊ pɹɛzənt, aɪd swænə saɪdweɪz, bʌt sɛd nʌθɪŋ. peɪl ən bɔɪɪʃli slɪm, dʌsin lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli wɑnə bi ðɛɹ, ə pɹɪɾi, sʌlki bɔɪ hu hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡd sʌmwɛɹ baɪ hɪz ɪɹ. sɪɾɝz ɔfən bɔkt əɾ ɑɹm-twɪstɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ ədʒɑz hɛd, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt bɪɑn pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət swænə hæd faʊn səm weɪ.

Elaida studied her for a moment, then gave a satisfied nod. The woman's eyes still shone with emotion, though. Lifting the lid of one of the three lacquered boxes on her table, she took out a small, age-darkened ivory carving of a turtle and stroked it between her fingers. Fondling the carvings in that box was a habit she had when she wanted to soothe her nerves. "Now," she said. "You were explaining to me why I should enter negotiations." "We were not asking permission, Mother," Suana said sharply, thrusting her chin out. She had too much chin, a square stone of it, and the arrogance to thrust it at anyone. "A decision of this sort belongs to the Hall. There is strong feeling in favor of it in the Yellow Ajah." Which meant she had strong feelings. She was the head of the Yellow Ajah, the First Weaver, something Alviarin knew because the Black Ajah knew all the Ajah secrets, or nearly all, and in Suana's view, her opinions were her Ajah's opinions. Doesine, the other Yellow present, eyed Suana sideways, but said nothing. Pale and boyishly slim, Doesine looked as if she did not really want to be there, a pretty, sulky boy who had been dragged somewhere by his ear. Sitters often balked at arm-twisting from their Ajah's head, yet it was not beyond possibility that Suana had found some way.

"mɛni waɪts ɔlsoʊ səpɔɹt tɔks," fɛɹən sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ dɪstʃɹæktɪdli əɾ ən ɪŋk steɪn ɑn wʌn plʌmp fɪŋɡɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz ðə lɑdʒɪkəl θɪŋ tə du, ʌndɝ ðə pɹɛzən sɝkəmstænsəz." ʃi wɑz fɝst ɹizənɝ, hɛɾ ə ðə waɪɾ ədʒɑ, bʌt lɛs laɪkli ðən swænə tə teɪk əɹ oʊn vjuz fəɹ ðoʊz ə ði ɪntaɪɝ ədʒɑ. ə lɪɾəl lɛs laɪkli. fɛɹən ɔfən simd əz veɪɡ əz ðə wɝst ə ðə bɹaʊnz - ðə lɔŋ blæk hɛɹ ðət fɹeɪmd əɹ ɹaʊn feɪs niɾəd ə bɹʌʃ, ən pɑɹɾ ə ðə fɹɪnʒ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn dɪp kɛɹləsli ɪn əɹ bɹɛkfəs ti - bʌt ʃi kəd kætʃ ðə slaɪɾəst kɹæk ɪn ðə lɑdʒɪk ʌv ən ɑɹɡjəmənt. ʃi maɪt wɛl əv bɪn ðəɹ baɪ hɝsɛlf kəz ʃi sɪmpli dɪd nɑt bɪliv ʃi niɾəd ɛni əsɪstəns fɹəm ði ʌðɝ waɪt sɪɾɝz.

"Many Whites also support talks," Ferane said, frowning distractedly at an ink stain on one plump finger. "It is the logical thing to do, under the present circumstances." She was First Reasoner, head of the White Ajah, but less likely than Suana to take her own views for those of the entire Ajah. A little less likely. Ferane often seemed as vague as the worst of the Browns - the long black hair that framed her round face needed a brush, and part of the fringe on her shawl appeared to have been dipped carelessly in her breakfast tea - but she could catch the slightest crack in the logic of an argument. She might well have been there by herself because she simply did not believe she needed any assistance from the other White Sitters.

linɪŋ bæk ɪn əɹ tɔl tʃɛɹ, ɪleɪɾə bɪɡæn tə ɡlaʊɝ, hɝ fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹoʊkɪŋ fæstɝ ɑn ðə tɝɾəl, ən ændaɪə spoʊk ʌp kwɪkli, nɑt kwaɪt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪɾə waɪl pɹitɛndɪŋ tə ədʒʌs ðə sɛɾ ə hɝ ɡɹeɪ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl əlɔŋ əɹ ɑɹmz.

Leaning back in her tall chair, Elaida began to glower, her fingers stroking faster on the turtle, and Andaya spoke up quickly, not quite looking at Elaida while pretending to adjust the set of her gray-fringed shawl along her arms.

"ðə pɔɪnt, mʌðɝ, ɪz ðət wi mʌs faɪn ə weɪ tə ɛn ðɪs pisfəli," ʃi sɛd, ðə tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛn stʃɹɔŋ ɪn əɹ spitʃ əz ɪt wɑz wən ʃi fɛlt ənizi. fɹikwənli dɪfəɾənt ɝaʊn ɪleɪɾə, ʃi ɡlænst ət jukɪɝi əz ðoʊ hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ səpɔɹt, bʌt ðə slɛndɝ lɪɾəl wʊmən tɝn əɹ hɛɾ əsaɪd slaɪtli. jukɪɝi wɑz ɹɪmɑɹkəbli stʌbɝn fəɹ sətʃ ə taɪni wʊmən; ənlaɪk dʌsin, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɹɪspɑndɪd tə ɑɹm-twɪstɪŋ. soʊ waɪ wɑz ʃi hɪɹ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi? ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ oʊn, ændaɪə ɹʌʃt ɑn. "ɪt mʌs nɑt bi əlaʊd tə kʌm tə faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. əɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ; ɪspɛʃli nɑt ðæt; nɑɾ əɡɛn. soʊ fɑɹ, ðə ɹɛbəlz sim kɑntɛn tə sɪɾ ən wɑtʃ ðə sɪɾi, bʌt ðət kænɑt læst. ðeɪv ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd haʊ tə tʃɹævəl, mʌðɝ, ən əv juzd ɪt tə kæɹi ən ɑɹmi əkɹɔs hʌnʒɹədz ə liɡz. wi mʌs bɪɡɪn tɔks bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dɪsaɪd tə juz tʃɹævlɪŋ tə bɹɪŋ ðəɾ ɑɹmi ɪndə tɑɹ vəlɑn, əɹ ɔl ɪz lɔst ivən ɪf wi wɪn."

"The point, Mother, is that we must find a way to end this peacefully," she said, the Taraboner accent strong in her speech as it was when she felt uneasy. Frequently diffident around Elaida, she glanced at Yukiri as though hoping for support, but the slender little woman turned her head aside slightly. Yukiri was remarkably stubborn for such a tiny woman; unlike Doesine, she would not have responded to arm-twisting. So why was she here if she did not want to be? Realizing that she was on her own, Andaya rushed on. "It must not be allowed to come to fighting in the streets of Tar Valon. Or in the Tower; especially not that; not again. So far, the rebels seem content to sit and watch the city, but that cannot last. They have rediscovered how to Travel, Mother, and have used it to carry an army across hundreds of leagues. We must begin talks before they decide to use Traveling to bring that army into Tar Valon, or all is lost even if we win."

fɪsts nɑɾɪd ɪn əɹ skɝts, ɑlviɛɝɪn swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ʃi θɔɾ əɹ aɪz maɪt pɑp aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd. ðə ɹɛbəlz nu haʊ tə tʃɹævəl? ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ ət tɑɹ vəlɑn ɔlɹɛɾi? ən ðiz fulz wɑntəd tə tɔk? ʃi kəd si kɛɹfəli leɪd plænz, kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd dɪzaɪnz, ɪvæpɝeɪɾɪŋ laɪk mɪst ɪn ə sʌmɝ sʌn. pɝhæps ðə dɑɹk lɔɹd wəd lɪsən, ɪf ʃi pɹeɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd. ɪleɪɾəz skaʊl dɪd nɑt dɪmɪnɪʃ, bʌt ʃi sɛt ði aɪvɝi tɝɾəl daʊn vɛɹi kɛɹfəli, ən əɹ vɔɪs keɪm kloʊs tə nɔɹməl. ði oʊl nɔɹməl, bɪfɔɹ ɑlviɛɝɪn ɹeɪn əɹ ɪn, wɪð ə stil kɔɹ bɪniθ ðə sɔfnəs ə ðə wɝdz. "du ðə bɹaʊn ən ðə ɡɹin ɔlsoʊ səpɔɹt tɔks?"

Fists knotted in her skirts, Alviarin swallowed hard. She thought her eyes might pop out of her head. The rebels knew how to Travel? They were here at Tar Valon already? And these fools wanted to talk? She could see carefully laid plans, carefully arranged designs, evaporating like mist in a summer sun. Perhaps the Dark Lord would listen, if she prayed very hard. Elaida's scowl did not diminish, but she set the ivory turtle down very carefully, and her voice came close to normal. The old normal, before Alviarin reined her in, with a steel core beneath the softness of the words. "Do the Brown and the Green also support talks?"

"ðə bɹaʊn," ʃɛvən bɪɡæn, ðən pɝst əɹ lɪps ɪn θɔɾ ən vɪzəbli tʃeɪnʒd wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə seɪ. aʊtwɝdli, ʃi simd ʌɾɝli kəmpoʊzd, jɛt ʃi wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ lɔŋ θʌmz əɡɛnst əɹ boʊni fɔɹfɪŋɝz ʌnkɑnʃəsli. "ðə bɹaʊn ɪz kwaɪt klɪɹ ɑn ðə hɪstɔɹɪkəl pɹɛsəɾənts. juv ɔl ɹɛd ðə sikɹət hɪstɝiz, əɹ ʃəd hæv. wɛnɛvɝ ðə taʊɝ əz bɪn dɪvaɪɾəd əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf, dɪzæstɝ əz stʃɹʌk ðə wɝld. wɪð ðə læs bæɾəl lumɪŋ, ɪn ə wɝl ðət kənteɪnz ðə blæk taʊɝ, wi kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɔɹd tə ɹɪmeɪn dɪvaɪɾəd ə deɪ lɔŋɡɝ ðən nid bi."

"The Brown," Shevan began, then pursed her lips in thought and visibly changed what she had intended to say. Outwardly, she seemed utterly composed, yet she was rubbing her long thumbs against her bony forefingers unconsciously. "The Brown is quite clear on the historical precedents. You have all read the secret histories, or should have. Whenever the Tower has been divided against itself, disaster has struck the world. With the Last Battle looming, in a world that contains the Black Tower, we can no longer afford to remain divided a day longer than need be."

ɪt hɑɹdli sim ðəɾ ɪleɪɾəz feɪs kəd ɡɹoʊ dɑɹkɝ, bʌt mɛnʃən ə ðə blæk taʊɝ dɪɾ ɪt.

It hardly seemed that Elaida's face could grow darker, but mention of the Black Tower did it.

"æn ðə ɡɹin?" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz stɪl kəntʃɹoʊld.

"And the Green?" Her voice was still controlled.

ɔl θɹi ɡɹin sɪɾɝz wɝ ðɛɹ, ɪndəkeɪɾɪŋ vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ səpɔɹɾ əmʌŋ ðɛɹ ədʒɑ, əɹ hɛvi pɹɛʃɝ fɹəm ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡɹin. əz sinjɝ, tælin ʃʊɾə ænsɝɾ ɪleɪɾə - ɡɹinz stʌk tə ðɛɹ haɪɹɑɹkiz ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ - bʌt ðə tɔl, ɡoʊldɪnhɛɹd wʊmən ɡlænst ət jukɪɝi fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðən dʒʌst əz ɑdli, ət dʌsin, ən pʊɾ əɹ aɪz ɑn ðə kɑɹpəɾ ən stʊd plʌkɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɡɹin sɪlk skɝts.

All three Green Sitters were there, indicating very strong support among their Ajah, or heavy pressure from the head of the Green. As senior, Talene should have answered Elaida - Greens stuck to their hierarchies in everything - but the tall, goldenhaired woman glanced at Yukiri for some reason, then just as oddly, at Doesine, and put her eyes on the carpet and stood plucking at her green silk skirts.

ɹinə fɹaʊn feɪnli, ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ əɹ ʌptɝnd noʊz ɪn pʌzəlmənt, bʌt ʃi hæd wɔɹn ðə ʃɔl fəɹ fjuɝ ðən fɪfti jɪɹz, soʊ ɪt wɑz lɛf tə ɹubɪn tə ɹɪplaɪ. ə stɝɾi wʊmən, ɹubɪn əpɪɹd ʃɔɹɾ ən stɑki əlɔŋsaɪd tælin, ən ɔlmoʊs pleɪn dɪspaɪɾ aɪz ðə kʌlɝ ə sæfaɪɝz.

Rina frowned faintly, wrinkling her upturned nose in puzzlement, but she had worn the shawl for fewer than fifty years, so it was left to Rubinde to reply. A sturdy woman, Rubinde appeared short and stocky alongside Talene, and almost plain despite eyes the color of sapphires.

"aɪ æm ɪnstʃɹʌktəd tə meɪk ðə seɪm pɔɪns əz ʃɛvən," ʃi sɛd, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə stɑɹɾəld lʊk ðət ɹinə ɡeɪv hɝ. pleɪnli ðəɹ hæd bɪn pɹɛʃɝ fɹəm ædlɔɹnə, ðə ɡɹin 'kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl,' ən pleɪnli ɹubɪn dɪsəɡɹiɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə meɪk ɪt pʌblɪk. "tɑɹmən ɡdən ɪz kʌmɪŋ, ðə blæk taʊɝ ɪz ɔlmoʊst əz ɡɹeɪɾ ə θɹɛt, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz mɪsɪŋ, ɪf i ɪzən dɛd. wi kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əfɔɹd tə bi dɪvaɪɾəd. ɪf ændaɪə kən tɔk ðə ɹɛbəlz bæk ɪndə ðə taʊɝ, ðən wi mʌs lɛɾ əɹ tʃɹaɪ."

"I am instructed to make the same points as Shevan," she said, ignoring the startled look that Rina gave her. Plainly there had been pressure from Adelorna, the Green 'Captain-General,' and plainly Rubinde disagreed if she was willing to make it public. "Tarmon Gai'don is coming, the Black Tower is almost as great a threat, and the Dragon Reborn is missing, if he isn't dead. We can no longer afford to be divided. If Andaya can talk the rebels back into the Tower, then we must let her try."

"aɪ si," ɪleɪɾə sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt toʊn. bʌt stʃɹeɪnʒli, hɝ kʌlɝ ɪmpɹuvd, ən ðə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl ivən tʌtʃt əɹ maʊθ. "ðɛn baɪ ɔl minz, tɔk əm bæk, ɪf jə kæn. bʌt maɪ iɾɪkts stænd. ðə blu ədʒɑ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪsts, ən ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u fɑloʊz ðət tʃaɪld ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ mʌst sɝv pɛnəns ʌndɝ maɪ ɡaɪɾəns bɪfɔɹ ʃi kən bi ɹiədmɪɾɪd tə ɛni ədʒɑ. aɪ ɪntɛn tə wɛl ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪndə ə wɛpən tə juz ət tɑɹmən ɡdən."

"I see," Elaida said in a flat tone. But strangely, her color improved, and the hint of a smile even touched her mouth. "Then by all means, talk them back, if you can. But my edicts stand. The Blue Ajah no longer exists, and every sister who follows that child Egwene al'Vere must serve penance under my guidance before she can be readmitted to any Ajah. I intend to weld the White Tower into a weapon to use at Tarmon Gai'don."

fɛɹən ən swænə oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz, pɹoʊɾɛst peɪntəɾ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə kʌɾ əm ɔf wɪð ə ɹeɪz hænd. "aɪ hæv spoʊkən, dɔɾɝz. liv mi naʊ. ən si tə jəɹ . . . tɔks." ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðə sɪɾɝz kəd də ʃɔɹɾ ʌv oʊpən dɪfaɪəns.

Ferane and Suana opened their mouths, protest painted on their faces, but Elaida cut them off with a raised hand. "I have spoken, daughters. Leave me now. And see to your . . . talks." There was nothing the Sitters could do short of open defiance.

wʌt wɑz ðə hɔlz ɹaɪt wɑz ðɛɹz, bʌt ðə hɔl sɛldəm dɛɹɾ ɪnfɹɪnʒ fɑɹ ɑn ði æmɪɝlɪn sits əθɔɹəɾi. nɑɾ ənlɛs ðə hɔl wɑz junaɪɾəd əɡɛns ði æmɪɝlɪn, ən ðɪs hɔl wɑz ɛniθɪŋ bʌt junaɪɾəd ɑn ɛni pɔɪnt. ɑlviɛɝɪn hæd hɛlpt ɪnʃʊɹ ðət hɝsɛlf. ðeɪ lɛft, fɛɹən ən swænə, stɪf-bækt ən taɪt-lɪpt, ændaɪə, ɔlmoʊst skɝiɪŋ. nʌn ə ðɛm soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ɪn ɑlviɛɝɪnz dɝɛkʃən.

What was the Hall's right was theirs, but the Hall seldom dared infringe far on the Amyrlin Seat's authority. Not unless the Hall was united against the Amyrlin, and this Hall was anything but united on any point. Alviarin had helped insure that herself. They left, Ferane and Suana, stiff-backed and tight-lipped, Andaya, almost scurrying. None of them so much as glanced in Alviarin's direction.

ʃi bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ tə kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðə læst. "ðɪs ɹɪli tʃeɪnʒəz nʌθɪŋ, ɪleɪɾə, ʃʊɹli jə si ðæt. jə mʌs θɪŋk klɪɹli, nɑt tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ə moʊməntɛɹi æbɝeɪʃən." ʃi nu ʃi wɑz bæbəlɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt sim tə stɑp. "ðə dɪzæstɝ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, ðə sɝɾən dɪzæstɝ ət ðə blæk taʊɝ, ðiz kən stɪl ənsit ju. jə nid mi tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðə stæf ən stoʊl. jə nid mi, ɪleɪɾə. ju. . . . " ʃi klæmpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌt bɪfɔɹ əɹ tʌŋ θɹu ɛvɹiθɪŋ əweɪ. ðəɹ stɪl hæd tə bi ə weɪ. "aɪm sɝpɹaɪz jə ɹɪtɝnd," ɪleɪɾə sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən smuðɪŋ əɹ ɹɛd-slæʃt skɝts. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɡɪvən ʌp əɹ weɪ ʌv dʒɹɛsɪŋ əz ə ɹɛd. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ əz ʃi keɪm ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. nɑɾ ə hɪn əɾ ə smaɪl, bʌɾ ə fʊl, pliz kɝv ə hɝ lɪps. "hæv jə bɪn haɪɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi sɪns ðə ɹɛbəlz ɝaɪvd? aɪ θɔt juɾ əv teɪkən ʃɪp əz sun əz jə lɝn ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ.

She barely waited for the door to close behind the last. "This really changes nothing, Elaida, surely you see that. You must think clearly, not trip over a momentary aberration." She knew she was babbling, but she could not seem to stop. "The disaster at Dumai's Wells, the certain disaster at the Black Tower, these can still unseat you. You need me to hold on to the staff and stole. You need me, Elaida. You. . . . " She clamped her teeth shut before her tongue threw everything away. There still had to be a way. "I'm surprised you returned," Elaida said, rising and smoothing her red-slashed skirts. She had never given up her way of dressing as a Red. Strangely, she was smiling as she came around the table. Not a hint at a smile, but a full, pleased curve of her lips. "Have you been hiding somewhere in the city since the rebels arrived? I thought you'd have taken ship as soon as you learned they were here.

hu wʊɾə θɔt ðeɪ wəd ɹiɾɪskʌvɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ? ɪmædʒən wʌt wi kən də wʌns wi noʊ ðæt." smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpət.

Who would have thought they would rediscover Traveling? Imagine what we can do once we know that." Smiling, she glided across the carpet.

"naʊ lemi si. wʌt də aɪ hæv tə fɪɹ fɹəm ju? ðə stɔɹiz aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin ɑɹ ðə tɔk ə ðə taʊɝ, bʌɾ ivən ɪf sɪstɝz ɹɪli wɝ oʊbeɪɪŋ ði ælθɹ bɔɪ, wɪtʃ aɪ fəɹ wʌn kænɑt bɪliv, ɛvɹiwʌn bleɪmz kɔɪɹən. ʃi hæd ðə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ʌv bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪm hɪɹ, ən ʃiz əz ɡʊɾ əz bɪn tʃɹaɪɾ ən kənvɪktəd, ɪn ðə maɪnz ə ðə sɪstɝz." ɪleɪɾə stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɑlviɛɝɪn, hɛmɪŋ əɹ ɪndə ðə kɔɹnɝ.

"Now let me see. What do I have to fear from you? The stories out of Cairhien are the talk of the Tower, but even if sisters really were obeying the al'Thor boy, which I for one cannot believe, everyone blames Coiren. She had the responsibility of bringing him here, and she has as good as been tried and convicted, in the minds of the sisters." Elaida stopped in front of Alviarin, hemming her into the corner.

ðət smaɪl nɛvɝ tʌtʃt əɹ aɪz. ʃi smaɪld, ən əɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd. ɑlviɛɝɪn kəd nɑt bɹeɪk əweɪ fɹəm ðət ɡeɪz. "ɪn ðə læst wik, wiv hɝɾ ə ɡʊd mɛni θɪŋz əbaʊt ðə 'blæk taʊɝ,' əz wɛl." ɪleɪɾəz lɪps twɪstəɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst ɝaʊn ðə neɪm. "ɪt simz ðəɹ ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ mɛn ðən jə səpoʊzd.

That smile never touched her eyes. She smiled, and her eyes glittered. Alviarin could not break away from that gaze. "In the last week, we've heard a good many things about the 'Black Tower,' as well." Elaida's lips twisted in disgust around the name. "It seems there are even more men than you supposed.

bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn θɪŋks tʌvaɪn mʌst əv hæd ðə sɛns tə lɝn ðət bɪfɔɹ ʃi ətækt. ðəɹ əz bɪn ə ɡʊd dil ə dɪskʌʃən oʊvɝ ɪt. ɪf ʃi kʌmz dʒɹæɡɪŋ bæk hɪɹ dɪfiɾəd, ʃɪl hɑɹvəs ðə bleɪm. soʊ jəɹ θɹɛts. . . ."

But everyone thinks Toveine must have had the sense to learn that before she attacked. There has been a good deal of discussion over it. If she comes dragging back here defeated, she will harvest the blame. So your threats. . . ."

ɑlviɛɝɪn stæɡɝɾ ɪndə ðə wɔl, blɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ spɑts, bɪfɔɹ ʃi ivən ɹilaɪz ðət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd slæp hɝ. hɝ tʃik ɔlɹɛɾi fɛl swoʊlən. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ hæd sɝaʊndəɾ ɪleɪɾə, ən ðə ʃil sɛɾəld ɑn ɑlviɛɝɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd twɪtʃ, kʌɾɪŋ əɹ ɔf fɹəm ðə paʊɝ. bʌɾ ɪleɪɾə dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə juz ðə paʊɝ. ʃi dʒɹu bæk ə fɪst. stɪl smaɪlɪŋ.

Alviarin staggered into the wall, blinking away spots, before she even realized that the other woman had slapped her. Her cheek already felt swollen. The glow of saidar had surrounded Elaida, and the shield settled on Alviarin before she could twitch, cutting her off from the Power. But Elaida did not intend to use the Power. She drew back a fist. Still smiling.

sloʊli, ðə wʊmən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ əɹ hæn fɔl. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹimuv ðə ʃild, haʊɛvɝ. "wʊd jə ɹɪli jus ðæt?" ʃi æskt ɪn ən ɔlmoʊs maɪl toʊn.

Slowly, the woman drew a deep breath and let her hand fall. She did not remove the shield, however. "Would you really use that?" she asked in an almost mild tone.

ɑlviɛɝɪnz hæn spɹæŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɪlt ə hɝ bɛl naɪf. ɡɹæbɪŋ ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɹiflɛks, bʌɾ ivən ɪf ɪleɪɾə hæd nɑt bɪn hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, kɪlɪŋ əɹ wən soʊ mɛni sɪɾɝz nu ðeɪ wɝ təɡɛðɝ wʊɾə bɪn əz ɡʊɾ əz kɪlɪŋ hɝsɛlf. stɪl, hɝ feɪs bɝnd wən ɪleɪɾə snɪf kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "aɪ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə siɪŋ jəɹ nɛk stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ðə hɛdzmənz blɑk fəɹ tʃɹizən, ɑlviɛɝɪn, bʌɾ əntɪl aɪ hæv ðə pɹuf aɪ nid, ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl ə fju θɪŋz aɪ kən du. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ mɛni taɪmz jə hæd sɪlviænə kʌm tə ɡɪmi pɹaɪvət pɛnəns? aɪ hoʊp jə du, kəz jə ɑɹ gɑnə teɪk tɛn fəɹ ɛvɹi deɪ aɪ sʌfɝd. ænd, oʊ, jɛs." wɪð ə dʒɝk, ʃi pʊl ðə kipɝz stoʊl ɹʌfli fɹəm ɑlviɛɝɪnz nɛk.
