"sɪns noʊ wʌn kəd faɪn jə wən ðə ɹɛbəlz ɝaɪvd, aɪ æsk ðə hɔl tə ɹimuv jə əz kipɝ. nɑt ðə fʊl hɔl, ʌv kɔɹs. jə meɪ stɪl əv ə lɪɾəl ɪnfluəns ðɛɹ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli izi tə ɡeɪn ðə kənsɛnsəs fɹəm ðoʊz u wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ðət deɪ. eɪ kipɝ ɪz səpoʊz tə bi wɪð əɹ æmɪɝlɪn, nɑt wɑndɝɪŋ ɔf ɑn əɹ oʊn. ɑn sɛkən θɔt, jə meɪ nɑɾ əv ɛni ɪnfluəns əɾ ɔl, sɪns ɪt tɝnz aʊt jə wɝ haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɔl əlɔŋ. əɹ dɪd jə seɪl bæk tə faɪn dɪzæstɝ, ən æktʃəli  θɪŋk jə kəd ɹɪkʌvɝ sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹuənz? "noʊ mæɾɝ. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn bɛɾɝ fəɹ jə tə lip ɑn ðə fɝst ʃɪp jə kəd faɪn livɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn. bʌɾ aɪ mʌst ədmɪt, ðə θɔɾ ə jə skʌɾəlɪŋ fɹəm vɪlədʒ tə vɪlədʒ əʃeɪm tə ʃoʊ jəɹ feɪs tə ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ peɪlz bɪsaɪd ðə plɛʒɝ əl teɪk siɪŋ jə sʌfɝ. naʊ ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt bɪfɔɹ aɪ dɪsaɪɾ ɪt ʃəd bi ðə bɝtʃ ɹæðɝ ðən sɪlviænəz stʃɹæp." tɔsɪŋ ðə waɪt stoʊl tə ðə flɔɹ, ʃi tɝn əɹ bæk ən ɹilist seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ əz ɪf ɑlviɛɝɪn hæd sis tə ɪɡzɪst.

Alviarin's hand sprang away from the hilt of her belt knife. Grabbing it had been a reflex, but even if Elaida had not been holding the Power, killing her when so many Sitters knew they were together would have been as good as killing herself. Still, her face burned when Elaida sniffed contemptuously. "I look forward to seeing your neck stretched on the headsman's block for treason, Alviarin, but until I have the proof I need, there are still a few things I can do. Do you remember how many times you had Silviana come to give me private penance? I hope you do, because you are going to take ten for every day I suffered. And, oh, yes." With a jerk, she pulled the Keeper's stole roughly from Alviarin's neck. "Since no one could find you when the rebels arrived, I asked the Hall to remove you as Keeper. Not the full Hall, of course. You may still have a little influence there. But it was surprisingly easy to gain the consensus from those who were sitting that day. A Keeper is supposed to be with her Amyrlin, not wandering off on her own. On second thought, you may not have any influence at all, since it turns out you were hiding in the city all along. Or did you sail back to find disaster, and actually think you could recover something from the ruins? "No matter. It might have been better for you to leap on the first ship you could find leaving Tar Valon. But I must admit, the thought of you scuttling from village to village ashamed to show your face to another sister pales beside the pleasure I'll take seeing you suffer. Now get out of my sight before I decide it should be the birch rather than Silviana's strap." Tossing the white stole to the floor, she turned her back and released saidar, gliding toward her chair as if Alviarin had ceased to exist.

ɑlviɛɝɪn dɪd nɑt liv, ʃi flɛd, ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð ðə fil ə ðə dɑɹkhaʊnz' bɹɛθ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ nɛk. ʃi hæd bɛɹli bɪn eɪbəl tə θɪŋk sɪns ʃi hɝd ðə wɝd tʃɹizən. ðət wɝd, ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn əɹ hɛd, meɪɾ əɹ wɑnə haʊl. tʃɹizən kəɾ oʊnli min wʌn θɪŋ. ɪleɪɾə nu, ən ʃi wɑz sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ pɹuf. ðə dɑɹk lɔɹɾ əv mɝsi. bʌɾ i nɛvɝ dɪd. mɝsi wɑz fəɹ ðoʊz əfɹeɪd tə bi stʃɹɔŋ. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. ʃi wɑz ə skɪn stʌf tə bɝstɪŋ wɪð tɛɹɝ.

Alviarin did not leave, she fled, running with the feel of the Darkhounds' breath on the back of her neck. She had barely been able to think since she heard the word treason. That word, echoing in her head, made her want to howl. Treason could only mean one thing. Elaida knew, and she was searching for proof. The Dark Lord have mercy. But he never did. Mercy was for those afraid to be strong. She was not afraid. She was a skin stuffed to bursting with terror.

bæk daʊn θɹu ðə taʊɝ ʃi flɛd, ən ɪf ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə sɝvən ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz, ʃi dɪd nɑt si hɪm. hɔɹɝ blaɪndɪɾ əɹ aɪz tə ɛniθɪŋ nɑt dɝɛkli ɪn əɹ pæθ. ɔl ðə weɪ bæk daʊn tə ðə sɪksθ lɛvəl ʃi ɹæn, tə hɝ oʊn əpɑɹtməns. ət list, ʃi səpoʊz ðeɪ wɝ stɪl hɝz fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ðə ɹumz wɪð ðɛɹ bælkəni oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt skwɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə taʊɝ wɛnt wɪð ði ɔfəs ə kipɝ. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf ðət ʃi stɪl hæd ɹumz. ən ə tʃæns tə lɪv. ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ stɪl ðə dəmɑni pisəz lɛf baɪ ðə pɹiviəs ɑkjəpənt, ɔl peɪl stʃɹaɪpt wʊɾ ɪnleɪd wɪð pɝlʃɛl ən æmbɝ. ɪn ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ʃi θɹu oʊpən wʌn ə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz ən fɛl tə hɝ niz, pʊʃɪŋ əsaɪd dʒɹɛsəz tə ɹʌmɪdʒ ɪn ðə bæk fəɹ ə smɔl tʃɛst, ə bɑks lɛs ðən tu hænz skwɛɹ, ðət hæd bɪn hɝz fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz. ðə kɑɹvɪŋ ɑn ðə bɑks wɑz ɪntʃɹəkət bʌt klʌmzi, ɹoʊz ə vɛɹid nɑts əpɛɹənli dʌn baɪ ə kɑɹvɝ wɪð mɔɹ æmbɪʃən ðən skɪl. hɝ hænz ʃʊk əz ʃi kæɹiɾ ɪt tə ə teɪbəl, ən ʃi sɛɾ ɪt daʊn tə waɪp klæmi pɑmz ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs. ðə tʃɹɪk tə oʊpənɪŋ ðə bɑks wɑz sɪmpli ə mæɾɝ ə spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ tə pɹɛs saɪməlteɪniəsli ət fɔɹ nɑts ɪn ðə kɑɹvɪŋ, noʊ tu əlaɪk. ðə lɪd lɪftəd slaɪtli, ən ʃi θɹu ɪt bæk, ɹɪvilɪŋ əɹ moʊs pɹɛʃəs pəzɛʃən ɹæpt ɪn ə smɔl bʌndəl ə bɹaʊn klɔθ tə kip ɪt fɹəm ɹætlɪŋ ɪf ə meɪd ʃʊk ðə bɑks.

Back down through the Tower she fled, and if there was so much as a servant in the hallways, she did not see him. Horror blinded her eyes to anything not directly in her path. All the way back down to the sixth level she ran, to her own apartments. At least, she supposed they were still hers for the moment. The rooms with their balcony overlooking the great square in front of the Tower went with the office of Keeper. For the moment, it was enough that she still had rooms. And a chance to live. The furnishings were still the Domani pieces left by the previous occupant, all pale striped wood inlaid with pearlshell and amber. In the bedchamber, she threw open one of the wardrobes and fell to her knees, pushing aside dresses to rummage in the back for a small chest, a box less than two hands square, that had been hers for many years. The carving on the box was intricate but clumsy, rows of varied knots apparently done by a carver with more ambition than skill. Her hands shook as she carried it to a table, and she set it down to wipe clammy palms on her dress. The trick to opening the box was simply a matter of spreading her fingers as wide as they would go to press simultaneously at four knots in the carving, no two alike. The lid lifted slightly, and she threw it back, revealing her most precious possession wrapped in a small bundle of brown cloth to keep it from rattling if a maid shook the box.

moʊs taʊɝ sɝvəns wəd nɑt ɹɪsk stilɪŋ, bʌt moʊs dɪd nɑt min ɔl.

Most Tower servants would not risk stealing, but most did not mean all.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɑlviɛɝɪn oʊnli stɛɹɾ ət ðə pækədʒ. hɝ moʊs pɹɛʃəs pəzɛʃən, ə θɪŋ fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ dɛɹd juz ɪt bɪfɔɹ. oʊnli ɪn ðə wɝst ɪmɝdʒənsi, mɛsænə hæd sɛd, ðə moʊs dɛspɹɪt nid, jɛt wʌt nid kəd bi mɔɹ daɪɹ ðən ðɪs? mɛsænə sɛd ðə θɪŋ kəd teɪk hæmɝ bloʊz wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ, bʌt ʃi əndɪd ðə ɹæpɪŋz wɪð ðə kɛɹ ʃi wʊɾə juzd wɪð ə pis ə faɪn bloʊn ɡlæs, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ə bɹɪljən ɹɛd ɹɑd noʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən əɹ fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ, ʌɾɝli smuð ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju faɪn laɪnz wɝkt ɪndə ðə sɝfəs ɪn ə sɪnwəs ɪntɝkənɛktɪŋ pæɾɝn.

For a moment, Alviarin only stared at the package. Her most precious possession, a thing from the Age of Legends, but she had never dared use it before. Only in the worst emergency, Mesaana had said, the most desperate need, yet what need could be more dire than this? Mesaana said the thing could take hammer blows without breaking, but she undid the wrappings with the care she would have used with a piece of fine blown glass, revealing a ter'angreal. a brilliant red rod no larger than her forefinger, utterly smooth except for a few fine lines worked into the surface in a sinuous interconnecting pattern.

ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs, ʃi tʌtʃt ðət pæɾɝn wɪð hɛɹ-θɪn floʊz ə faɪɝ ən ɝθ ət tu ʌv ði ɪntɝkənɛkʃənz. ðət wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn nɛsəsɛɹi ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ kɔl ðə "stændɪŋ floʊz" noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪɡzɪstəd. ə wɝld wɛɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛni tɛɹæŋɡɹil kəd bi juz baɪ pipəl əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl simd ɑd bɪɑn kɑmpɹihɛnʃən. waɪ hæɾ ɪt bɪn əlaʊd?

Embracing the Source, she touched that pattern with hair-thin flows of Fire and Earth at two of the interconnections. That would not have been necessary in the Age of Legends, but something called the "standing flows" no longer existed. A world where almost any ter'angreal could be used by people unable to channel seemed odd beyond comprehension. Why had it been allowed?

pɹɛsɪŋ wʌn ɛn ə ðə ɹɑd hɑɹd wɪð əɹ θʌm - ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf, baɪ ɪtsɛlf - ʃi sæt daʊn hɛvəli ən lin əɡɛns ðə tʃɛɹz loʊ bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə θɪŋ ɪn əɹ hænd. ɪt wɑz dʌn.

Pressing one end of the rod hard with her thumb - the One Power was not enough, by itself - she sat down heavily and leaned against the chair's low back, staring at the thing in her hand. It was done.

ʃi fɛl hɑloʊ, naʊ, ə væst ɛmpti speɪs wɪð fɪɹz flʌɾɝɪŋ θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs laɪk ɪnɔɹməs bæts.

She felt hollow, now, a vast empty space with fears fluttering through the darkness like enormous bats.

ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹiɹæpɪŋ ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ʃi tʌkt ɪɾ ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ ən ɡɑɾ ʌp lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stʌf ðə bɑks bæk ɪndə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb. əntɪl ʃi nu ʃi wɑz seɪf, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə lɛt ðət ɹɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ pəzɛʃən. bʌt ðən ɔl ʃi kəd də wɑz sɪɾ ən weɪt, ɹɑkɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ wɪð əɹ hænz klæsp bɪtwin əɹ niz. ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ɹɑkɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi kəd stɑp ðə loʊ moʊnz ðət tʃɹɪkəl bɪtwin əɹ tiθ. sɪns ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə taʊɝ, noʊ sɪstɝ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn tʃɑɹdʒd wɪð biɪŋ blæk ədʒɑ. oʊ, ðəɹ hæd bɪn səspɪʃənz baɪ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl sɪstɝz, ən fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd daɪd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðoʊz səspɪʃənz nɛvɝ wɛn fɝðɝ, bʌt nɛvɝ hæɾ ɪt kʌm tə əfɪʃəl tʃɑɹdʒəz. ɪf ɪleɪɾə wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə spik oʊpənli ʌv ðə hɛdzmənz blɑk, ʃi mʌs bi kloʊs tə bɹɪŋɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒəz. vɛɹi kloʊs. blæk sɪstɝz hæd bɪn meɪd tə dɪsəpɪɹ, tu, wən səspɪʃənz ɡɹu tu ɡɹeɪt. ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd stɑp moʊnɪŋ.

Instead of rewrapping the ter'angreal, she tucked it into her belt pouch and got up long enough to stuff the box back into the wardrobe. Until she knew she was safe, she did not intend to let that rod out of her possession. But then all she could do was sit and wait, rocking back and forth with her hands clasped between her knees. She could not stop rocking any more than she could stop the low moans that trickled between her teeth. Since the founding of the Tower, no sister had ever been charged with being Black Ajah. Oh, there had been suspicions by individual sisters, and from time to time Aes Sedai had died to make sure those suspicions never went further, but never had it come to official charges. If Elaida was willing to speak openly of the headsman's block, she must be close to bringing charges. Very close. Black sisters had been made to disappear, too, when suspicions grew too great. The Black Ajah remained hidden whatever the cost. She wished she could stop moaning.

sʌɾənli ðə laɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹum dɪmd, ɪnvɛləpɪŋ ðə tʃeɪmbɝ ɪn swɝlɪŋ twaɪlaɪt ʃædoʊz.

Suddenly the light in the room dimmed, enveloping the chamber in swirling twilight shadows.

ðə sʌnlaɪɾ ət ðə keɪsməns simd əneɪbəl tə pɛnətʃɹeɪt bɪɑn ðə ɡlæs peɪnz. ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz ɑn əɹ niz ɪn ə bɹɛθ, aɪz daʊn. ʃi tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð wɑntɪŋ tə pɔɹ aʊɾ əɹ fɪɹz, bʌt wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən, ðə fɔɹmz mʌs bi fɑloʊd. "aɪ lɪv tə sɝv, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd, ən nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. ʃi kəd nɑt weɪst ə moʊmənt, mʌtʃ lɛs ən aʊɝ skɹimɪŋ ɪn peɪn. hɝ hænz wɝ klʌtʃt təɡɛðɝ tə kip əm fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ.

The sunlight at the casements seemed unable to penetrate beyond the glass panes. Alviarin was on her knees in a breath, eyes down. She trembled with wanting to pour out her fears, but with the Chosen, the forms must be followed. "I live to serve, Great Mistress," she said, and nothing more. She could not waste a moment, much less an hour screaming in pain. Her hands were clutched together to keep them from shaking.

"wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ ɡɹeɪv ɪmɝdʒənsi, tʃaɪld?" ɪt wɑz ə wʊmənz vɔɪs, bʌɾ ə vɔɪs ə kɹɪstəl tʃaɪmz.

"What is your grave emergency, child?" It was a woman's voice, but a voice of crystal chimes.

dɪspliz tʃaɪmz. oʊnli dɪsplizd.

Displeased chimes. Only displeased.

æŋɡɹi tʃaɪmz maɪɾ əv mɛn dɛθ ɑn ðə spɑt. "ɪf, jə θɪŋk əl ɹeɪz ə fɪŋɡɝ tə ɡɛt ðə kipɝz stoʊl bæk fəɹ ju, jə ɑɹ sædli mɪsteɪkən. jə kən stɪl də wʌɾ aɪ wɪʃ dʌn, wɪð ə lɪɾəl ɛkstʃɹə ɛfɝt. ən jə meɪ kənsɪɾɝ jəɹ pɛnənsɪz wɪð ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ə smɔl pʌnɪʃmən fɹəm mi. aɪ dɪd wɔɹn jə əbaʊt pʊʃɪŋ ɪleɪɾə kwaɪt soʊ hɑɹd."

Angry chimes might have meant death on the spot. "If, you think I will raise a finger to get the Keeper's stole back for you, you are sadly mistaken. You can still do what I wish done, with a little extra effort. And you may consider your penances with the Mistress of Novices a small punishment from me. I did warn you about pushing Elaida quite so hard."

ɑlviɛɝɪn swɑloʊɾ əɹ pɹoʊɾɛsts. ɪleɪɾə wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən tə bɛnd wɪθaʊt hɑɹd pʊʃɪŋ.

Alviarin swallowed her protests. Elaida was not a woman to bend without hard pushing.

mɛsænə hæd tə noʊ ðæt. bʌt pɹoʊɾɛsts kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən. mɛni θɪŋz wɝ deɪnʒɝəs, wɪð ðə tʃoʊzən. ɪn ɛni keɪs, sɪlviænəz stʃɹæp wɑz ə tʃɹaɪfəl kəmpɛɹd tə ðə hɛdzmənz æks.

Mesaana had to know that. But protests could be dangerous, with the Chosen. Many things were dangerous, with the Chosen. In any case, Silviana's strap was a trifle compared to the headsman's axe.

"ɪleɪɾə noʊz, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs," ʃi bɹiðd, ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ aɪz. ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ stʊɾ ə wʊmən ə laɪt-ænd-ʃædoʊ, kloʊðd ɪn laɪt-ænd-ʃædoʊ, ɔl stɑɹk blæks ən sɪlvɝi waɪts ðət floʊd fɹəm wʌn tə ði ʌðɝ ən bæk. sɪlvɝ aɪz fɹaʊn fɹəm ə feɪs ə smoʊk, wɪð sɪlvɝ lɪps dʒɹɔn ɪn ə taɪt laɪn. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ɪluʒən, ən ɹɪli nɑt dʌn ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən ɑlviɛɝɪn kəd hæv. ə flæʃ ʌv ɡɹin sɪlk skɝɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ɪlæbɹət bænz ə bɹɑnz ʃoʊɾ əz mɛsænə ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə dəmɑni kɑɹpət. bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn kəd nɑt si ðə wivz ðət meɪd ði ɪluʒən ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæd fɛl ðoʊz ðə wʊmən hæd juz tə ɝaɪv əɹ kæs ðə ɹum ɪn ʃædoʊz. fəɹ ɔl ʃi kəd sɛns, mɛsænə kəd nɑt tʃænəl əɾ ɔl! ðə lʌs fəɹ ðoʊz tu sikɹəts juʒəwəli kʌɾ ət hɝ, bʌt tədeɪ ʃi hɑɹdli noʊɾəst. "ʃi noʊz aɪm blæk ədʒɑ, ɡɹeɪt mɪstʃɹəs. ɪf ʃiz ənkʌvɝd mi, ðən ʃiz hæd sʌmwʌn dɪɡɪŋ dip. dʌzənz ʌv əs meɪ bi ət ɹɪsk, pɝhæps ɔl ʌv ʌs." bɛs tə meɪk ə θɹɛɾ əz lɑɹdʒ əz pɑsəbəl ɪf jə wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ ʌv ə ɹɪspɑns. ɪt maɪɾ ivən bi soʊ.

"Elaida knows, Great Mistress," she breathed, raising her eyes. In front of her stood a woman of light-and-shadow, clothed in light-and-shadow, all stark blacks and silvery whites that flowed from one to the other and back. Silver eyes frowned from a face of smoke, with silver lips drawn in a tight line. It was only Illusion, and really not done any better than Alviarin could have. A flash of green silk skirt embroidered with elaborate bands of bronze showed as Mesaana glided across the Domani carpet. But Alviarin could not see the weaves that made the Illusion any more than she had felt those the woman had used to arrive or cast the room in shadows. For all she could sense, Mesaana could not channel at all! The lust for those two secrets usually cut at her, but today she hardly noticed. "She knows I am Black Ajah, Great Mistress. If she has uncovered me, then she has had someone digging deep. Dozens of us may be at risk, perhaps all of us." Best to make a threat as large as possible if you wanted to be sure of a response. It might even be so.

bʌt mɛsænəz ɹɪspɑns wɑz ə dɪsmɪsɪv weɪv ʌv wʌn naʊ-sɪlvɝ hænd. hɝ feɪs ɡloʊd laɪk ə mun ɝaʊn aɪz blækɝ ðən koʊlz. "ðæɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs. ɪleɪɾə kænɑt dɪsaɪd fɹəm wʌn deɪ tə ðə nɛkst wɛðɝ ʃi ivən bɪlivz ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪɡzɪsts. jə ɑɹ dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə seɪv jɝsɛlf ə lɪɾəl peɪn.

But Mesaana's response was a dismissive wave of one now-silver hand. Her face glowed like a moon around eyes blacker than coals. "That is ridiculous. Elaida cannot decide from one day to the next whether she even believes the Black Ajah exists. You are just trying to save yourself a little pain.

pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ wɪl ɪnstʃɹʌk jə ɪn jəɹ ɛɹɝ." ɑlviɛɝɪn bɪɡæn tə pliɾ əz mɛsænə ɹeɪz ðət hæn haɪɝ, ən ə wiv ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd mʌtʃ tu wɛl fɔɹmd ɪn ði ɛɹ. ʃi hæd tə meɪk ðə wʊmən ʌndɝstænd!

Perhaps a little more will instruct you in your error." Alviarin began to plead as Mesaana raised that hand higher, and a weave she remembered much too well formed in the air. She had to make the woman understand!

əbɹʌpli, ðə ʃædoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum lɝtʃt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ sim tə ʃɪf saɪdweɪz əz ðə dɑɹknəs θɪkən ɪn mɪdnaɪt lʌmps.

Abruptly, the shadows in the room lurched. Everything seemed to shift sideways as the darkness thickened in midnight lumps.

ən ðən ðə dɑɹknəs wɑz ɡɔn. stɑɹɾəld, ɑlviɛɝɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪð əɹ bɛɡɪŋ hænz stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp təwɔɹɾ ə blu-aɪd wʊmən ə flɛʃ ən blʌd, ɡɑɹbd ɪn bɹɑnz-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin. ə tæntəlaɪzɪŋli fəmɪljɝ wʊmən u lʊk dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ʃi hæd noʊn mɛsænə wɔk ðə taʊɝ dɪsɡaɪzd əz wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz, ðoʊ noʊ tʃoʊzən ʃi hæd mɛt ʃoʊɾ ɛni saɪn ʌv eɪɡləsnəs, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt mætʃ ðət feɪs tə ɛni neɪm. ən ʃi ɹilaɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, əz wɛl.

And then the darkness was gone. Startled, Alviarin found herself with her begging hands stretched up toward a blue-eyed woman of flesh and blood, garbed in bronze-embroidered green. A tantalizingly familiar woman who looked just short of her middle years. She had known Mesaana walked the Tower disguised as one of the sisters, though no Chosen she had met showed any sign of agelessness, but she could not match that face to any name. And she realized something else, as well.

ðət feɪs wɑz əfɹeɪd. haɪɾɪŋ ɪt, bʌɾ əfɹeɪd.

That face was afraid. Hiding it, but afraid.

"ʃiz bɪn vɛɹi jusfəl," mɛsænə sɛd, nɑt saʊndɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ əɾ ɔl, ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət tʌɡd ði ɛdʒ ə ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən, "ænd naʊ əl əv tə kɪl hɝ."

"She's been very useful," Mesaana said, not sounding afraid at all, in a voice that tugged the edge of recognition, "and now I will have to kill her."

"ju wɝ ɔlweɪz . . . oʊvɝli weɪsfəl," ɹɪplaɪɾ ə hɑɹʃ vɔɪs, laɪk ɹɑɾən boʊn kɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝfʊt.

"You were always . . . overly wasteful," replied a harsh voice, like rotten bone crumbling underfoot.

ɑlviɛɝɪn fɛl oʊvɝ ɪn ʃɑk ət ðə tɔl ʃeɪp ʌv ə mæn ɪn sɪnwəs blæk ɑɹmɝ, ɔl oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts laɪk ðə skeɪlz ʌv ə sneɪk, stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn wɪndoʊ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə mæn, ðoʊ. ðət blʌdləs feɪs hæd noʊ aɪz, dʒʌst smuð dɛd waɪt skɪn wɛɹ ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv bɪn. ʃi hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝd mɹdʒɹɑl bɪfɔɹ, ɪn ðə sɝvəs ə ðə dɑɹk lɔɹd, ən ivən mænədʒ tə mit ðɛɹ aɪləs ɡeɪzəz wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ weɪ tə ðə tɛɹɝ ðoʊz stɛɹz ɛndʒɛndɝd, bʌt ðɪs wʌn meɪɾ əɹ skɹæbəl bæk əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ əntɪl əɹ bæk dʒɑɹɾ ə lɛɡ ʌv ðə teɪbəl. lɝks wɝ əlaɪk əz tu ɹeɪndʒɹɑps, tɔl ən lin ən aɪdɛntɪkəl, bʌt ðɪs wʌn stʊɾ ə hɛd tɔlɝ, ən fɪɹ sim tə ɹeɪɾiət fɹəm ɪt, soʊkɪŋ ɪndə hɝ boʊnz.

Alviarin fell over in shock at the tall shape of a man in sinuous black armor, all overlapping plates like the scales of a snake, standing in front of one window. It was not a man, though. That bloodless face had no eyes, just smooth dead white skin where they should have been. She had encountered Myrddraal before, in the service of the Dark Lord, and even managed to meet their eyeless gazes without giving way to the terror those stares engendered, but this one made her scrabble back across the floor until her back jarred a leg of the table. Lurks were alike as two raindrops, tall and lean and identical, but this one stood a head taller, and fear seemed to radiate from it, soaking into her bones.

ənθɪŋkɪŋ, ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɹs. ən nɪɹli skɹimd. ðə sɔɹs wɑz ɡɔn! ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃildɪd; ðəɹ wɑz sɪmpli nʌθɪŋ ðəɹ fəɹ əɹ tə ɛmbɹeɪs! ðə mɹdʒɹɑl lʊkt əɾ əɹ ən smaɪld.

Unthinking, she reached for the Source. And nearly screamed. The Source was gone! She was not shielded; there was simply nothing there for her to embrace! The Myrddraal looked at her and smiled.

lɝks nɛvɝ smaɪld.

Lurks never smiled.

nɛvɝ. hɝ bɹɛθ keɪm ɪn ɹæɡəd pæntɪŋ.

Never. Her breath came in ragged panting.

"ʃi kən bi jusfəl," ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɹæspt. "aɪ wəd nɑt wɑn ðə blæk ədʒɑ dɪstʃɹɔɪd."

"She can be useful," the Myrddraal rasped. "I would not want the Black Ajah destroyed."

"hu ɑɹ jə tə tʃælənʒ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən?" mɛsænə dɪmændəd kəntɛmptʃwəsli, ðən ɹuən ði ɪfɛk baɪ lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps.

"Who are you to challenge one of the Chosen?" Mesaana demanded contemptuously, then ruined the effect by licking her lips.

"du jə θɪŋk hæn ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz dʒʌst ə neɪm?" ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz vɔɪs noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɡɹeɪɾɪd.

"Do you think Hand of the Shadow is just a name?" The Myrddraal's voice no longer grated.

hɑloʊ, ɪt sim tə bum daʊn kævɝnz fɹəm səm ʌnɪmædʒɪnəbəl dɪstəns. ðə kɹitʃɝ ɡɹu əz ɪt spoʊk, swɛlɪŋ ɪn saɪz tɪl ɪts hɛd bɹʌʃt ðə silɪŋ, oʊvɝ tu spænz ʌp. "ju wɝ sʌmənd, ən jə dɪd nɑt kʌm. maɪ hæn ɹitʃəz fɑɹ, mɛsænə."

Hollow, it seemed to boom down caverns from some unimaginable distance. The creature grew as it spoke, swelling in size till its head brushed the ceiling, over two spans up. "You were summoned, and you did not come. My hand reaches far, Mesaana."

ʃeɪkɪŋ vɪzəbli, ðə tʃoʊzən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, pɝhæps tə plid, bʌt sʌɾənli blæk faɪɝ flæʃt ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ʃi skɹimd əz əɹ kloʊðɪŋ fɛl əweɪ ɪn dʌst. bænz ə blæk fleɪm baʊn əɹ ɑɹmz tə hɝ saɪdz, ɹæp taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ lɛɡz, ən ə siθɪŋ bɔl ə blæk əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ maʊθ, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ dʒɔz waɪd. ʃi ɹɪθ ðɛɹ, stændɪŋ neɪkəɾ ən hɛlpləs, ən ðə lʊk ɪn əɹ ɹoʊlɪŋ aɪz meɪɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑnə sɔɪl hɝsɛlf. "du jə wɑnə noʊ waɪ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən mʌs bi pʌnɪʃt?" ðə vɔɪs wɑz ə boʊn-ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ ɹæsp wʌns mɔɹ, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl simɪŋli oʊnli ə tu-tɔl lɝk, bʌɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz nɑt fuld. "du jə wɑnə wɑtʃ?" ɪɾ æskt.

Shaking visibly, the Chosen opened her mouth, perhaps to plead, but suddenly black fire flashed around her, and she screamed as her clothing fell away in dust. Bands of black flame bound her arms to her sides, wrapped tight around her legs, and a seething ball of black appeared in her mouth, forcing her jaws wide. She writhed there, standing naked and helpless, and the look in her rolling eyes made Alviarin want to soil herself. "Do you want to know why one of the Chosen must be punished?" The voice was a bone-grating rasp once more, the Myrddraal seemingly only a too-tall Lurk, but Alviarin was not fooled. "Do you want to watch?" it asked.

ʃi ʃəd ɡoʊ feɪsdaʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ɡɹɑvəl fəɹ əɹ laɪf, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt muv. ʃi kəd nɑt lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðəɾ aɪləs stɛɹ. "noʊ, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd," ʃi mænədʒd wɪð ə maʊθ əz dʒɹaɪ əz dʌst. ʃi nu. ɪt kəd nɑt bi, bʌt ʃi nu. tɪɹz wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks, ʃi ɹilaɪzd.

She should go facedown on the floor, grovel for her life, but she could not move. She could not look away from that eyeless stare. "No, Great Lord," she managed with a mouth as dry as dust. She knew. It could not be, but she knew. Tears were rolling down her cheeks, she realized.

ðə mɹdʒɹɑl smaɪld əɡɛn. "mɛni hæv fɔlən fɹəm ɡɹeɪt haɪts fəɹ wɑntɪŋ tə noʊ tu mʌtʃ."

The Myrddraal smiled again. "Many have fallen from great heights for wanting to know too much."

ɪt floʊd təwɔɹɾ əɹ - noʊ; nɑɾ ɪt - ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, kloʊðd ɪn ðə skɪn ʌv ə mɹdʒɹɑl, floʊd təwɔɹd hɝ. hi wɔkt ɑn lɛɡz, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ dɪskɹɪpʃən fəɹ ðə weɪ hi muvd. ðə peɪl, blæk-klæd ʃeɪp bɛn təwɔɹd hɝ, ən ʃi wʊɾə ʃɹikt wən i tʌtʃt ə fɪŋɡɝ tə hɝ fɔɹhɛd. ʃi wʊɾə ʃɹikt ɪf ʃi cʊɾə sʌmən ɛni saʊn əɾ ɔl. hɝ lʌŋz wɝ ɛɹləs sæks. ðə tʌtʃ bɝn laɪk ɹɛd-hɑɾ aɪɝn. veɪɡli, ʃi wʌndɝd waɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt smɛl əɹ oʊn flɛʃ bɝnɪŋ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd stʃɹeɪɾənd, ən ðə sɪɹɪŋ peɪn dwɪndəld, vænɪʃt. hɝ tɛɹɝ dɪd nɑt lɛsən ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst, ðoʊ.

It flowed toward her - no; not it - the Great Lord, clothed in the skin of a Myrddraal, flowed toward her. He walked on legs, yet there was no other description for the way he moved. The pale, black-clad shape bent toward her, and she would have shrieked when he touched a finger to her forehead. She would have shrieked if she could have summoned any sound at all. Her lungs were airless sacks. The touch burned like red-hot iron. Vaguely, she wondered why she did not smell her own flesh burning. The Great Lord straightened, and the searing pain dwindled, vanished. Her terror did not lessen in the slightest, though.

"ju ɑɹ mɑɹkt əz maɪn," ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd ɹæspt. "mɛsænə wɪl nɑt hɑɹm ju, naʊ. ənlɛs aɪ ɡɪv əɹ pɝmɪʃən. jəl faɪn u θɹɛɾənz maɪ kɹitʃɝz hɪɹ ən dɪlɪvɝ əm tə mi." hi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ, ən ðə dɑɹk ɑɹmɝ fɛl fɹəm ɪz bɑɾi. ʃi wɑz stɑɹɾəld wən ɪt hɪt ðə kɑɹpəɾɪd flɔɹ taɪlz wɪð ə kɹæʃ ə stil ɹæðɝ ðən sɪmpli vænɪʃɪŋ. hi wɑz kloʊðd ɪn blæk, ən ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz sɪlk əɹ lɛðɝ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. ðə dɑɹknəs ʌv ɪt sim tə dʒɹɪŋk ðə laɪt fɹəm ðə ɹum. mɛsænə bɪɡæn tə θɹæʃ ɪn əɹ bɑnz, kinɪŋ ʃɹɪli pæs ðə ɡæɡ ɪn əɹ maʊθ. "ɡoʊ naʊ," hi sɛd, "ɪf jə wɪʃ tə lɪv ənʌðɝ aʊɝ." ðə saʊn kʌmɪŋ fɹəm mɛsænə ɹoʊz tə ə dɪspɛɹɪŋ skɹim.

"You are marked as mine," the Great Lord rasped. "Mesaana will not harm you, now. Unless I give her permission. You will find who threatens my creatures here and deliver them to me." He turned away from her, and the dark armor fell from his body. She was startled when it hit the carpeted floor tiles with a crash of steel rather than simply vanishing. He was clothed in black, and she could not have said whether it was silk or leather or something else. The darkness of it seemed to drink the light from the room. Mesaana began to thrash in her bonds, keening shrilly past the gag in her mouth. "Go now," he said, "if you wish to live another hour." The sound coming from Mesaana rose to a despairing scream.

ɑlviɛɝɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ ʃi ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹumz - ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn haʊ ʃi wɑz əpɹaɪt wən əɹ lɛɡz fɛlt laɪk wɔɾɝ - bʌt ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz, skɝts pʊl tə hɝ niz ən ɹʌnɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. sʌɾənli ðə hɛɾ ʌv ə waɪd stɛɹkeɪs lumd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən ʃi bɛɹli mænədʒ tə stɑp fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. sæɡɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ʃeɪkɪŋ, ʃi stɛɹd daʊn ðə kɝvɪŋ flaɪɾ ʌv waɪt mɑɹbəl stɛps. ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ʃi kəd si hɝ bɑɾi bɹeɪkɪŋ əz ɪt kɹæʃt daʊn ðə stɛɹweɪ.

Alviarin did not know how she got out of her rooms - she could not understand how she was upright when her legs felt like water - but she found herself running through the corridors, skirts pulled to her knees and running as hard as she could. Suddenly the head of a wide staircase loomed in front of her, and she barely managed to stop from running right out into the air. Sagging against the wall, shaking, she stared down the curving flight of white marble steps. In her mind, she could see her body breaking as it crashed down the stairway.

bɹiðɪŋ ɹæədli, ɪn hɔɹs, ɹɔ-θɹoʊɾɪd pæns, ʃi pʊɾ ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hæn tə hɝ fɔɹhɛd. hɝ θɔts tʌmbəld wʌn oʊvɝ ənʌðɝ, əz ʃi wəɾ əv daʊn ðə stɛɹz. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd mɑɹkt əɹ əz hɪz. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz slɪɾ əkɹɔs smuð ənblɛmɪʃt skɪn. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz pɹaɪz nɑlədʒ - paʊɝ ɡɹu fɹəm nɑlədʒ  - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹumz ʃi hæd lɛft.

Breathing raggedly, in hoarse, raw-throated pants, she put a trembling hand to her forehead. Her thoughts tumbled one over another, as she would have down the stairs. The Great Lord had marked her as his. Her fingers slid across smooth unblemished skin. She had always prized knowledge - power grew from knowledge  - but she did not want to know what was happening in the rooms she had left.

ʃi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd mɑɹk hɝ, bʌt mɛsænə wəd faɪn ə weɪ tə kɪl hɝ, fəɹ noʊɪŋ ðæt. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd mɑɹkt əɹ ən ɡɪvən əɹ ə kəmænd. ʃi kəd lɪv, ɪf ʃi faʊn u wɑz hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ bæk wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi hɝidli skɹʌbd ət ðə tɪɹz ɑn əɹ tʃiks wɪð ðə hilz ə hɝ pɑmz. ʃi kəd nɑt pʊl əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɛɹz fɔlɪŋ əweɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ɪleɪɾə ʃʊɹli səspɛktəd hɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt, ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz mænjəfæktʃɝ ə hʌnt. ɪt dʒʌs hæd tə ɪnkluɾ ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf əz ə θɹɛt tə bi ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt.

She wished she did not know that anything was happening. The Great Lord had marked her, but Mesaana would find a way to kill her, for knowing that. The Great Lord had marked her and given her a command. She could live, if she found who was hunting the Black Ajah. Straightening her back with an effort, she hurriedly scrubbed at the tears on her cheeks with the heels of her palms. She could not pull her eyes away from the stairs falling away in front of her. Elaida surely suspected her, but if there was no more to it than that, she could always manufacture a hunt. It just had to include Elaida herself as a threat to be extinguished.

dɪlɪvɝd tə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz flʌɾɝd tə hɝ fɔɹhɛɾ əɡɛn. ʃi hæd ðə blæk ədʒɑ əɾ əɹ kəmænd. smuð, ənblɛmɪʃt skɪn. tælin hæd bɪn ðɛɹ, ɪn ɪleɪɾəz ɹumz. waɪ hæd ʃi lʊkt ət jukɪɝi ən dʌsin ðət weɪ? tælin wɑz blæk, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðəɾ ɑlviɛɝɪn wɑz, ʌv kɔɹs. wəɾ ɛni mɑɹk ʃoʊ ɪn ə mɪɹɝ? wɑz ðəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ʌðɝz kəd si? ɪf ʃi hæd tə mænjəfæktʃɝ ə skim fəɹ ɪleɪɾəz səpoʊz hʌntɝz, tælin maɪt bi ə pleɪs tə stɑɹt. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tʃɹeɪs ðə ɹuɾ ɛni mɛsədʒ wʊɾə teɪkən fɹəm hɑɹt tə hɑɹt bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹitʃt tælin, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðə stɛɹz, siɪŋ əɹ bɑɾi baʊns ən bɹeɪk ɪts weɪ tə ðə bɑɾəm. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hæd mɑɹk hɝ.

Delivered to the Great Lord. Her fingers fluttered to her forehead again. She had the Black Ajah at her command. Smooth, unblemished skin. Talene had been there, in Elaida's rooms. Why had she looked at Yukiri and Doesine that way? Talene was Black, though she did not know that Alviarin was, of course. Would any mark show in a mirror? Was there something that others could see? If she had to manufacture a scheme for Elaida's supposed hunters, Talene might be a place to start. She tried to trace the route any message would have taken from heart to heart before it reached Talene, but she could not stop staring down the stairs, seeing her body bounce and break its way to the bottom. The Great Lord had marked her.

tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu

CHAPTER 22

wʌn ænsɝ ɪvɑɹə weɪɾəd wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns waɪl ðə slɪm lɪɾəl æksɛptɪd pleɪs ðə ɹɪm sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ ɑn ə saɪd teɪbəl ən ənkʌvɝd ðə dɪʃ ə keɪks. ə ʃɔɹt wʊmən wɪð ə sɪɹiəs feɪs, peɪdʒɹə wɑz nɑt biɪŋ læɡɝd, əɹ ɹɪzɛnfəl oʊvɝ hævɪŋ tə spɛn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ fɛtʃɪŋ ən kæɹiɪŋ fəɹ ə sɪɾɝ, dʒʌs pɹɪsaɪs ən kɛɹfəl. ðoʊz wɝ jusfəl kwɑləɾiz, tə bi ɛnkɝɪdʒd. stɪl, wən ði æksɛptɪɾ æskt wɛðɝ ʃi ʃəd pɔɹ ðə waɪn, pɛvɑɹə sɛd kɹɪspli, "wi wɪl də fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz, tʃaɪld. jə meɪ weɪɾ ɪn ði æntəɹum." ʃi ɔlmoʊs toʊl ðə jʌŋ wʊmən tə ɡoʊ bæk tə hɝ stʌɾiz.

One Answer evara waited with a touch of impatience while the slim little Accepted placed the rimmed silver tray on a side table and uncovered the dish of cakes. A short woman with a serious face, Pedra was not being laggard, or resentful over having to spend the morning fetching and carrying for a Sitter, just precise and careful. Those were useful qualities, to be encouraged. Still, when the accepted asked whether she should pour the wine, Pevara said crisply, "We will do for ourselves, child. You may wait in the anteroom." She almost told the young woman to go back to her studies.

peɪdʒɹə spɹɛɾ əɹ bændɪd waɪt skɝts ɪn ə ɡɹeɪsfəl kɝtsi wɪθaʊɾ ɛni saɪn ə biɪŋ flʌstɝd ðə weɪ æksɛptɪɾ ɔfən wɝ wən ə sɪɾɝ ʃoʊd snæpɪʃnəs. ɔl tu fɹikwənli, æksɛptɪd tʊk ɛni baɪɾ ɪn ə sɪɾɝz toʊn əz ən əpɪnjən ɑn ðɛɹ fɪtnəs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl, əz ɪf sɪɾɝz hæd noʊ ʌðɝ kənsɝnz.

Pedra spread her banded white skirts in a graceful curtsy without any sign of being flustered the way Accepted often were when a Sitter showed snappishness. All too frequently, Accepted took any bite in a Sitter's tone as an opinion on their fitness for the shawl, as if Sitters had no other concerns.

pɛvɑɹə weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn peɪdʒɹə ən ðə lætʃ klɪk bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ əpɹuvɪŋli. "ðæt wʌn wɪl bi ɹeɪzd ɛɛs sədaɪ sun," ʃi sɛd. ɪt wɑz sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ wən ɛni wʊmən əteɪn ðə ʃɔl, bʌɾ ɪspɛʃli wən ðə wʊmən hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ənpɹɔmɪsɪŋ tə bɪɡɪn wɪð. smɔl plɛʒɝz sim ði oʊnli wʌnz əveɪləbəl, ðiz deɪz.

Pevara waited until the door closed behind Pedra and the latch clicked before nodding approvingly. "That one will be raised Aes Sedai soon," she said. It was satisfying when any woman attained the shawl, but especially when the woman had appeared unpromising to begin with. Small pleasures seemed the only ones available, these days.

"nɑt wʌn ʌv aʊɝz, ðoʊ, aɪ θɪŋk" wɑz ðə ɹɪplaɪ fɹəm əɹ sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ɡɛst, hu tɝn fɹəm ə stʌɾi ʌv ðə ɹoʊ ʌv peɪntəd mɪniətʃɝz ə pɛvɑɹəz dɛd fæmli ðət stʊɾ ɪn ə laɪn ɑn ðə weɪvkɑɹv mɑɹbəl mæntəl əbʌv ðə faɪɝpleɪs. "ʃiz ənsɝɾən əbaʊt mɛn. aɪ bɪliv ðeɪ meɪk əɹ nɝvəs." tɑɹnə sɝɾənli hæd nɛvɝ bɪn nɝvəs əbaʊt mɛn əɹ vɛɹi mʌtʃ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ət lis nɑt sɪns ʃi ɹitʃt ðə ʃɔl dʒʌst oʊvɝ twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ. pɛvɑɹə kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ə vɛɹi dʒʌmpi nɑvəs, bʌt ðə peɪl-hɛɹd wʊmənz blu aɪz wɝ stɛɾi əz stoʊnz, naʊ. ən əbaʊɾ əz wɔɹm əz stoʊnz ɪn wɪntɝ. ivən soʊ, ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðət kul pɹaɪdfəl feɪs, sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛɾ ə hɝ maʊθ, ðət meɪɾ əɹ sim ənizi ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. pɛvɑɹə kəd hɑɹdli ɪmædʒən wʌt maɪt meɪk tɑɹnə fiɹ nɝvəs.

"Not one of ours, though, I think" was the reply from her surprising guest, who turned from a study of the row of painted miniatures of Pevara's dead family that stood in a line on the wavecarved marble mantel above the fireplace. "She's uncertain about men. I believe they make her nervous." Tarna certainly had never been nervous about men or very much of anything else, at least not since she reached the shawl just over twenty years ago. Pevara could remember a very jumpy novice, but the pale-haired woman's blue eyes were steady as stones, now. And about as warm as stones in winter. Even so, there was something in that cool prideful face, something in the set of her mouth, that made her seem uneasy this morning. Pevara could hardly imagine what might make Tarna Feir nervous.

ðə ɹil kwɛstʃən, ðoʊ, wɑz waɪ ðə wʊmən hæd kʌm tə si hɝ. ɪt bɔɹɾɝd ɑn ɪmpɹəpɹaɪəɾi fəɹ əɹ tə vɪzəɾ ɛni sɪɾɝ pɹaɪvətli, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ə ɹɛd. tɑɹnə stɪl meɪnteɪn əɹ ɹumz hɪɹ ɪn ðə ɹɛd kɔɹɾɝ, bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi hɛld əɹ nu pəzɪʃən, ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ dɪspaɪt ðə kɹɪmzən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs. dɪleɪɪŋ ðə muv tə hɝ nu əpɑɹtmən maɪt bi teɪkən əz ə ʃoʊ ʌv dɛləkəsi, baɪ ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt noʊ hɝ.

The real question, though, was why the woman had come to see her. It bordered on impropriety for her to visit any Sitter privately, particularly a Red. Tarna still maintained her rooms here in the Red quarter, but so long as she held her new position, she was no longer part of the Red Ajah despite the crimson embroidery on her dark gray dress. Delaying the move to her new apartment might be taken as a show of delicacy, by those who did not know her.

ɛniθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi meɪd pɛvɑɹə wɛɹi sɪns sin hæd pʊld əɹ ɪndə hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ədʒɑ. ən ɪleɪɾə tʃɹʌstɪd tɑɹnə, dʒʌst əz ʃi hæd tʃɹʌstɪd ɡəlinə; ɪt wɑz waɪz tə bi vɛɹi kɔʃəs wɪð ɛniwʌn ɪleɪɾə tʃɹʌstɪd. dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡəlinə - ðə laɪt bɝn ðə wʊmən fɝɛvɝ! - stɪl sɛt pɛvɑɹəz tiθ ɑn ɛdʒ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛkən kənɛkʃən. ɡəlinə hæd teɪkən ə spɛʃəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn tɑɹnə əz ə nɑvəs, tu. tʃɹu, ɡəlinə hæd teɪkən ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɛni nɑvəs əɹ æksɛptɪd ʃi θɔt maɪt dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ kɑʃən.

Anything out of the ordinary made Pevara wary since Seaine had pulled her into hunting the Black Ajah. And Elaida trusted Tarna, just as she had trusted Galina; it was wise to be very cautious with anyone Elaida trusted. Just thinking of Galina - the Light burn the woman forever! - still set Pevara's teeth on edge, but there was a second connection. Galina had taken a special interest in Tarna as a novice, too. True, Galina had taken an interest in any novice or Accepted she thought might join the Red, but it was another reason for caution.

nɑt ðət pɑvɑɹə lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʃoʊ ɑn əɹ feɪs, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ tu lɔŋ fəɹ ðæt. smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə lɔŋ-nɛk sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ ðət sæɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf ðə swit sɛn ə spaɪsəz. "wɪl jə teɪk waɪn, tɑɹnə, ɪn kənɡɹætʃəleɪʃən fəɹ biɪŋ ɹeɪzd?" sɪlvɝ ɡoʊbləts ɪn hænd, ðeɪ sɛɾəld ɑn spaɪɹəl-wɝkt ɑɹmtʃɛɹz, ə staɪl ðət hæd ɡɔn aʊɾ ə fæʃən ɪn kændɝ nɪɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ, bʌt wʌn ðət pɛvɑɹə laɪkt. ʃi sɔ noʊ ɹizən tə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ fɝnɪtʃɝ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə wɪmz ə ðə moʊmənt. ðə tʃɛɹz hæd sɝvd əɹ sɪns ðeɪ wɝ nu-meɪd, ən ðeɪ wɝ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ði ədɪʃən ʌv ə fju kʊʃənz. tɑɹnə sæt stɪfli, haʊɛvɝ, ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ sit. noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ kɔld əɹ læŋɡwəd, bʌt klɪɹli ʃi wɑz ənizi.

Not that Pavara let anything show on her face, of course. She had been Aes Sedai too long for that. Smiling, she reached for the long-necked silver pitcher that sat on the tray giving off the sweet scent of spices. "Will you take wine, Tarna, in congratulation for being raised?" Silver goblets in hand, they settled on spiral-worked armchairs, a style that had gone out of fashion in Kandor near a hundred years ago, but one that Pevara liked. She saw no reason to change her furniture or anything else according to the whims of the moment. The chairs had served her since they were new-made, and they were comfortable with the addition of a few cushions. Tarna sat stiffly, however, on the edge of her seat. No one had ever called her languid, but clearly she was uneasy.

"aɪ æm nɑt sɝɾən kənɡɹætʃəleɪʃənz ɑɹ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ," ʃi sɛd, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ ɹɛd stoʊl dʒɹeɪpt ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ði ɪɡzækt ʃeɪd wɑz nɑt pɹiskɹaɪbd, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u sɔ ɪt mʌs kɔl ðə kʌlɝ ɹɛd, ən ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən ə bɹɪljən skɑɹlət ðət nɪɹli ʃoʊn. "ɪleɪɾə ɪnsɪstəd, ən aɪ kəd nɑt ɹəfjuz.

"I am not certain congratulations are in order," she said, fingering the narrow red stole draped around her neck. The exact shade was not prescribed, except that anyone who saw it must call the color red, and she had chosen a brilliant scarlet that nearly shone. "Elaida insisted, and I could not refuse.

mʌtʃ əz tʃeɪnʒd sɪns aɪ lɛf ðə taʊɝ, ɪnsaɪɾ əz wɛl əz aʊt. ɑlviɛɝɪn meɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn . . . wɑtʃfəl . . .

Much has changed since I left the Tower, inside as well as out. Alviarin made everyone . . . watchful . . .

ʌv ðə kipɝ. aɪ səspɛk səm wɪl wɑn əɹ bɝtʃt, wən ʃi faɪnəli ɹɪtɝnz. ən ɪleɪɾə. . . . " ʃi pɔz tə sɪp əɾ əɹ waɪn, bʌt wən ʃi loʊɝd ðə ɡɑblət, ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə dɪfɹən veɪn. "aɪ hæv ɔfən hɝd jə kɔld ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl. aɪ hæv ivən hɝd ðət jə wʌns sɛd jə wəd laɪk tə hæv ə wɔɹɾɝ." "aɪv bɪn kɔld wɝs ðən ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl," pɛvɑɹə sɛd dʒɹaɪli. wʌt hæd ðə wʊmən bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ kənsɝnɪŋ ɪleɪɾə? ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wʊɾə ɹəfjuz ðə kipɝz stoʊl, ɡɪvən əɹ wɪʃɪz. stʃɹeɪnʒ. tɑɹnə wɑz hɑɹdli ʃaɪ əɹ ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ. saɪləns sim bɛst. ɪspɛʃli əbaʊt wɔɹɾɝz. ʃi hæd bɪn tɔkɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ɪt ðət wɑz dʒɛnɝəl ɡɑsəp. bɪsaɪdz, kip saɪlən lɔŋ ɪnʌf, ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɔlweɪz spoʊk ɪf oʊnli tə fɪl ʌp ðə ɡæp. jə kəd lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil θɹu saɪləns. ʃi sɪpt əɹ oʊn waɪn sloʊli. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ hʌni ɪn ɪt fəɹ əɹ teɪst, ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf dʒɪnʒɝ.

of the Keeper. I suspect some will want her birched, when she finally returns. And Elaida. . . . " She paused to sip at her wine, but when she lowered the goblet, she went on in a different vein. "I have often heard you called unconventional. I have even heard that you once said you would like to have a Warder." "I've been called worse than unconventional," Pevara said dryly. What had the woman been about to say concerning Elaida? She sounded as though she would have refused the Keeper's stole, given her wishes. Strange. Tarna was hardly shy or shrinking. Silence seemed best. Especially about Warders. She had been talking too much it that was general gossip. Besides, keep silent long enough, and the other woman always spoke if only to fill up the gap. You could learn a great deal through silence. She sipped her own wine slowly. There was too much honey in it for her taste, and not enough ginger.

stɪl stɪf, tɑɹnə ɹoʊz ən stʃɹoʊd tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, wɛɹ ʃi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə mɪniətʃɝz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ waɪt lækɝd stænz. ʃi ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə tʌtʃ wʌn ə ði aɪvɝi oʊvəlz, ən pɛvɑɹə fɛlt əɹ oʊn ʃoʊldɝz taɪɾən ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ɡeɪɔɹɡ, hɝ jʌŋɡəs bɹʌðɝ, hæd bɪn oʊnli twɛlv wən i daɪd, wən ɔl ə ðə pipəl ɪn ðoʊz peɪntɪŋz daɪd, ɪn ən əpɹaɪzɪŋ baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

Still stiff, Tarna rose and strode to the fireplace, where she stood staring at the miniatures sitting on their white lacquered stands. She raised a hand to touch one of the ivory ovals, and Pevara felt her own shoulders tighten in spite of herself. Georg, her youngest brother, had been only twelve when he died, when all of the people in those paintings died, in an uprising by Darkfriends.

ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ə fæmli hu kəɾ əfɔɹɾ aɪvɝi mɪniətʃɝz, bʌt wʌns ʃi hæd ðə kɔɪn, ʃi faʊn ə peɪntɝ u kəd kæptʃɝ əɹ mɛmɹiz. ə bjuɾəfəl bɔɪ, ɡeɪɔɹɡ, tɔl fəɹ ɪz jɪɹz ən ʌɾɝli fɪɹləs. lɔŋ æftɝ ði ɪvɛnt, ʃi hæd lɝn haʊ hɝ beɪbi bɹʌðɝ daɪd. wɪð ə naɪf ɪn ɪz hænd, stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ fɑðɝz bɑɾi ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðə mɑb fɹəm ðɛɹ mʌðɝ. soʊ mɛni jɪɹz əɡoʊ, naʊ.

They had not been a family who could afford ivory miniatures, but once she had the coin, she found a painter who could capture her memories. A beautiful boy, Georg, tall for his years and utterly fearless. Long after the event, she had learned how her baby brother died. With a knife in his hand, standing over their father's body and trying to keep the mob from their mother. So many years ago, now.

ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl əv bɪn lɔŋ dɛɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs, ən ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹənz tʃɪlʒɹənz tʃɪlʒɹən, əz wɛl. bʌt səm heɪtʃɹədz nɛvɝ daɪd. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz tɑvɝən, soʊ aɪ hæv hɝd," tɑɹnə sɛd faɪnəli, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət ɡeɪɔɹɡz pɪktʃɝ. "du jə θɪŋk i ɔltɝz tʃæns ɛvɹiwɛɹ? əɹ də wi tʃeɪnʒ ðə fjutʃɝ baɪ aʊɝsɛlvz, wʌn stɛp fɑloʊɪŋ ənʌðɝ əntɪl wi faɪn aʊɝsɛlvz sʌmwɛɹ wi nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd?"

They would all have been long dead in any case, and their children's children's children, as well. But some hatreds never died. "The Dragon Reborn is ta'veren, so I have heard," Tarna said finally, still staring at Georg's picture. "Do you think he alters chance everywhere? Or do we change the future by ourselves, one step following another until we find ourselves somewhere we never expected?"

"wʌt dʒju min?" pɛvɑɹə sɛd, ə tʃɹaɪfəl mɔɹ kɝtli ðən ʃi kəɾ əv wɪʃt. ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ði ʌðɝ wʊmən piɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ bɹʌðɝz ɪmədʒ soʊ ɪntɛnli waɪl tɔkɪŋ ʌv ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl, ivən ɪf i wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ʃi bɪɾ əɹ lɪp soʊ əz nɑt tə tɛl tɑɹnə tə tɝn ɝaʊn ən lʊk ət hɝ. jə kəd nɑt ɹɛd sʌmwʌnz bæk ðə weɪ jə kəɾ ə feɪs.

"What do you mean?" Pevara said, a trifle more curtly than she could have wished. She did not like the other woman peering at her brother's image so intently while talking of a man who could channel, even if he was the Dragon Reborn. She bit her lip so as not to tell Tarna to turn around and look at her. You could not read someone's back the way you could a face.

"aɪ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd noʊ ɡɹeɪt dɪfəkəlti ɪn sɑlədɑɹ. noʊ ɡɹeɪt səksɛs, iðɝ, bʌt wʌɾ aɪ faʊnd. . . ." wɑz ðəɾ ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, əɹ hæd ʃi mɪɹli tʃeɪnʒd ði æŋɡəl ət wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz piɹɪŋ ət ðə mɪniətʃʊɹ?

"I anticipated no great difficulty in Salidar. No great success, either, but what I found. . . ." Was that a shake of her head, or had she merely changed the angle at which she was peering at the miniature?

ʃi spoʊk sloʊli, bʌt wɪð ən ʌndɝkɝən ə ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɝdʒənsi. "aɪ lɛft ə pɪdʒən-hænlɝ ə deɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə vɪlədʒ, jɛɾ ɪt tʊk mi lɛs ðən hæf ə deɪ tə ɡɛt bæk tə hɝ, ən æftɝ aɪ lus ðə bɝdz wɪð kɑpiz ə maɪ ɹipɔɹt, aɪ pɹɛst ɑn soʊ hɑɹɾ aɪ hæd tə peɪ ðə wʊmən ɔf kəz ʃi kəd nɑt kip ʌp. aɪ kən hɑɹdli seɪ haʊ mɛni hɔɹsəz aɪ wɛn θɹu. səmtaɪmz, ði ænəməl wɑz spɛn tə ðə pɔɪn aɪ hæd tə ʃoʊ maɪ ɹɪŋ tə meɪk ə steɪbəl teɪk ɪɾ ɪn tʃɹeɪd, ivən wɪð sɪlvɝ æɾəd. ən kəz aɪ pɹɛst soʊ hɑɹd, aɪ hæpən tə ɹitʃ ə vɪlədʒ ɪn mʊɹændi waɪl ə . . . ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾi . . . wɑz ðɛɹ. ɪf aɪ hæd nɑt bɪn fɹaɪɾənd aʊɾ ə maɪ wɪts fəɹ ðə taʊɝ baɪ wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ɪn sɑlədɑɹ, aɪ wʊɾə ɹɪɾən tə ɛbu dɑɹ ən teɪkən ʃɪp fəɹ ɪljən ən ðən ʌpɹɪvɝ, bʌt ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ saʊθ ɪnstɛɾ ə nɔɹθ, ðə θɔɾ ʌv weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə vɛsəl, sɛn mi laɪk ən æɹoʊ təwɔɹd tɑɹ vəlɑn. soʊ aɪ wɑz ɪn ðət vɪlədʒ tə si ðɛm."

She spoke slowly, but with an undercurrent of remembered urgency. "I left a pigeon-handler a day outside the village, yet it took me less than half a day to get back to her, and after I loosed the birds with copies of my report, I pressed on so hard I had to pay the woman off because she could not keep up. I can hardly say how many horses I went through. Sometimes, the animal was spent to the point I had to show my ring to make a stable take it in trade, even with silver added. And because I pressed so hard, I happened to reach a village in Murandy while a . . . recruiting party . . . was there. If I had not been frightened out of my wits for the Tower by what I saw in Salidar, I would have ridden to Ebou Dar and taken ship for Illian and then upriver, but the thought of going south instead of north, the thought of waiting for a vessel, sent me like an arrow toward Tar Valon. So I was in that village to see them."

"hu, tɑɹnə?"

"Who, Tarna?"

"æʃəmən." ðə wʊmən dɪd tɝn ðɛn. hɝ aɪz wɝ stɪl blu aɪs, bʌt taɪt. ʃi hɛld əɹ ɡɑbləɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə soʊk ɪn ðə wɔɹmθ. "aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðɛn, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ oʊpənli ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ mɛn tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən ɪt simd waɪzəs tə lɪsən bɪfɔɹ aɪ spoʊk. wɛl fəɹ mi ðəɾ aɪ dɪd. ðəɹ wɝ sɪks ə ðɛm, pɛvɑɹə, sɪks mɛn ɪn blæk koʊts. tu wɪð sɪlvɝ sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ kɑlɝz wɝ filɪŋ mɛn aʊɾ əbaʊt wɛðɝ ðeɪ maɪt laɪk tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. oʊ, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ soʊ ɹaɪɾ aʊt. wil ðə laɪtnɪŋz, ðeɪ kɔld ɪt. wil ðə laɪtnɪŋz ən ɹaɪd ðə θʌndɝ.

"Asha'man." The woman did turn then. Her eyes were still blue ice, but tight. She held her goblet in both hands as if trying to soak in the warmth. "I did not know what they were then, of course, but they were openly recruiting men to follow the Dragon Reborn, and it seemed wisest to listen before I spoke. Well for me that I did. There were six of them, Pevara, six men in black coats. Two with silver swords on their collars were feeling men out about whether they might like to learn to channel. Oh, they did not say so right out. Wield the lightnings, they called it. Wield the lightnings and ride the thunder.

bʌɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ɪnʌf tə mi, ɪf nɑt tə ðə fulz ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə."

But it was clear enough to me, if not to the fools they were talking to."

"jɛs; vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ jə ðət jə kɛp saɪlənt," pɛvɑɹə sɛd kwaɪətli. "sɪks mɛn u kən tʃænəl wəd bi mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ə sɪstɝ baɪ hɝsɛlf. əɹ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɑɹ fʊl ə tɔk əbaʊt ðiz ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz - ðeɪ əpɪɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ fɹəm sɑldɑiə tə tɛɹ - bʌt noʊ wʌn simz tə hæv ən aɪdiə ʌv haʊ tə stɑp ðɛm. ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən tu leɪt fəɹ ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi." ʃi vɛɹi nɪɹli bɪɾ əɹ lɪp əɡɛn. ðət wɑz ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð tɔkɪŋ. səmtaɪmz, jə sɛd mɔɹ ðən jə wɑntəd.

"Yes; very well for you that you kept silent," Pevara said quietly. "Six men who can channel would be more than merely dangerous for a sister by herself. Our eyes-and-ears are full of talk about these recruiting parties - they appear everywhere from Saldaea to Tear - but no one seems to have an idea of how to stop them. If it isn't too late for that already." She very nearly bit her lip again. That was the trouble with talking. Sometimes, you said more than you wanted.

ɑdli, ðə kɑmɛn tʊk səm ə ðə stɪfnəs aʊɾ ə tɑɹnə. ʃi ɹɪzumd əɹ sit, linɪŋ bæk, ðoʊ ə hɪn ʌv wɛɹinɪs stɪl klʌŋ tə ðə weɪ ʃi hɛl hɝsɛlf. ʃi tʃoʊz əɹ wɝdz kɛɹfəli, pɔzɪŋ tə tʌtʃ ðə waɪn tə hɝ lɪps, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æktʃəli  dʒɹɪŋk, ðət pɛvɑɹə sɔ. "aɪ hæɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm tə θɪŋk ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝʃɪp kʌmɪŋ nɔɹθ. lɔŋɡɝ, æftɝ ðə ful kæptən ɹæn əs əɡɹaʊn soʊ hɑɹɾ i bɹoʊk ə mæst ən pʊɾ ə hoʊl ɪn ðə hʌl. deɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə heɪl ənʌðɝ ʃɪp, æftɝ wi ɡɑɾ əʃɔɹ, ən deɪz faɪndɪŋ ə hɔɹs. sɪks ə ðoʊz mɛn sɛn tə wʌn vɪlədʒ kənvɪns mi, faɪnəli. oʊ, ðə dɪstʃɹɪkt ɝaʊnd, əz wɛl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi pɑpjələs. aɪ. . . . aɪ ɪts ɪz tu leɪt."

Oddly, the comment took some of the stiffness out of Tarna. She resumed her seat, leaning back, though a hint of wariness still clung to the way she held herself. She chose her words carefully, pausing to touch the wine to her lips, but she did not actually drink, that Pevara saw. "I had a long time to think on the rivership coming north. Longer, after the fool captain ran us aground so hard he broke a mast and put a hole in the hull. Days trying to hail another ship, after we got ashore, and days finding a horse. Six of those men sent to one village convinced me, finally. Oh, the district around, as well, but it was not very populous. I. . . . I believe it is too late."

"ɪleɪɾə θɪŋks ðeɪ kən ɔl bi dʒɛntəld," pɛvɑɹə sɛd nɑnkəmɪɾəli. ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪkspoʊz hɝsɛlf tu mʌtʃ. "wɛn ðeɪ kən sɛn sɪks tə wʌn smɔl vɪlədʒ, ən tʃɹævəl? ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn ænsɝ aɪ kən si. wi. . . . " tɑɹnə tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə bɹaɪt ɹɛd stoʊl əɡɛn, bʌt naʊ ɪt simd mɔɹ ɪn ɹəɡɹɛt ðən tə pleɪ fəɹ taɪm. "ɹɛd sɪstɝz mʌs teɪk əm əz wɔɹɾɝz, pɛvɑɹə." ðət wɑz soʊ stɑɹtlɪŋ ðət pɛvɑɹə blɪŋkt. ə hɛɹ lɛs sɛlfkɑntʃɹɑl, ən ʃi wəɾ əv ɡeɪpt.

"Elaida thinks they can all be gentled," Pevara said noncommittally. She had already exposed herself too much. "When they can send six to one small village, and Travel? There is only one answer I can see. We. . . . " Tarna took a deep breath, fingering the bright red stole again, but now it seemed more in regret than to play for time. "Red sisters must take them as Warders, Pevara." That was so startling that Pevara blinked. A hair less selfcontrol, and she would have gaped.

"ɑɹ jə sɪɹiəs?" ðoʊz aɪsi blu aɪz mɛɾ əɹ ɡeɪz stɛɾəli. ðə wɝst wɑz pæs ði ənθɪŋkəbəl spoʊkən əlaʊd -  ən tɑɹnə wɑz ə wʊmən ə stoʊn wʌns mɔɹ. "ðɪs ɪz hɑɹdli ə mæɾɝ fəɹ dʒoʊkɪŋ. ði oʊnli ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs ɪz tə lɛɾ əm ɹʌn lus. hu ɛls kən də ɪt? ɹɛd sɪstɝz ɑɹ juz tə feɪsɪŋ mɛn laɪk ðɪs, ən ɹɛɾi tə teɪk ðə nɛsəsɛɹi ɹɪsks. ɛniwʌn ɛls wɪl flɪntʃ. itʃ sɪstɝ wɪl əv tə teɪk mɔɹ ðən wʌn, bʌt ɡɹinz əpɪɹ tə mænədʒ wɛl ɪnʌf wɪð ðæt. aɪ θɪŋk ðə ɡɹinz wɪl feɪn ɪf ðɪs ɪz sədʒɛstəd tə ðɛm, ðoʊ. wi . . . ɹɛd sɪstɝz . . . mʌs də wʌt nidz tə bi dʌn." "hæv jə bɹoʊtʃt ðɪs tə ɪleɪɾə?" pɛvɑɹə æskt, ən tɑɹnə ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli.

"Are you serious?" Those icy blue eyes met her gaze steadily. The worst was past the unthinkable spoken aloud -  and Tarna was a woman of stone once more. "This is hardly a matter for joking. The only other choice is to let them run loose. Who else can do it? Red sisters are used to facing men like this, and ready to take the necessary risks. Anyone else will flinch. Each sister will have to take more than one, but Greens appear to manage well enough with that. I think the Greens will faint if this is suggested to them, though. We . . . Red sisters . . . must do what needs to be done." "Have you broached this to Elaida?" Pevara asked, and Tarna shook her head impatiently.

"ɪleɪɾə bɪlivz əz jə sɛd. ʃi. . . . " ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd wʊmən fɹaʊn ɪndə hɝ waɪn bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ɪleɪɾə ɔfən bɪlivz wʌt ʃi wɑns tə bɪliv ən siz wʌt ʃi wɑns tə si. aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ ʌp ði æʃəmən ðə fɝs deɪ aɪ wɑz bæk. nɑt tə sədʒɛs bɑndɪŋ; nɑt tə hɝ. aɪm nɑɾ ə ful. ʃi fɝbeɪd mi tə mɛnʃən əm tə hɝ. bʌt jə ɑɹ . . . ʌnkənvɛnʃənəl." "æn dʒju bɪliv ðeɪ kən bi dʒɛntəld æftɝ ðəɹ bɑndəd? aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ðət wəd də tə ðə sɪstɝ hoʊldɪŋ ðə bɑnd, ən ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə lɝn." ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn pleɪɪŋ fəɹ taɪm, pɛvɑɹə ɹilaɪzd. ʃi hæd hæd noʊ aɪdiə wɛɹ ðɪs ɪntɝvju wɑz hɛɾəd wən ɪt bɪɡæn, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə weɪdʒɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi oʊn əɡɛnst ɪt kʌmɪŋ tə ðɪs.

"Elaida believes as you said. She. . . . " The yellow-haired woman frowned into her wine before going on. "Elaida often believes what she wants to believe and sees what she wants to see. I tried to bring up the Asha'man the first day I was back. Not to suggest bonding; not to her. I am not a fool. She forbade me to mention them to her. But you are . . . unconventional." "And do you believe they can be gentled after they're bonded? I have no idea what that would do to the sister holding the bond, and in truth, I don't want to learn." She was the one playing for time, Pevara realized. She had had no idea where this interview was headed when it began, but she would have wagered everything she owned against it coming to this.

"ðæt maɪt bi ði ɛnd, ən ɪt maɪt pɹuv ɪmpɑsəbəl," ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd kuli. ðə wʊmən wɑz stoʊn. "iðɝ weɪ, aɪ kən si noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ tə hændəl ðiz æʃəmən. ɹɛd sɪstɝz mʌs bɑn əm əz wɔɹɾɝz. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛni weɪ, əl bi əmʌŋ ðə fɝst, bʌɾ ɪt mʌs bi dʌn." ʃi sæt ðɛɹ, kɑmli sɪpɪŋ əɹ waɪn, ən fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, pɛvɑɹə kəɾ oʊnli stɛɹ əɾ əɹ ɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən. nʌθɪŋ tɑɹnə hæd sɛd pɹuvd ʃi wɑz nɑt blæk ədʒɑ, jɛt ʃi kəd nɑt dɪstʃɹʌst ɛvɹi sɪstɝ əneɪbəl tə pɹuv ðæt. wɛl, ʃi kəɾ ən dɪd, wən ɪt keɪm tə mæɾɝz ə ðə blæk, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ mæɾɝz ʃi hæd tə dil wɪð. ʃi wɑz ə sɪɾɝ, nɑt sɪmpli ə hʌntɪŋ dɔɡ. ʃi hæd ðə waɪt taʊɝ tə θɪŋk ʌv, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ. ən ðə fjutʃɝ.

"That might be the end, and it might prove impossible," the other woman replied coolly. The woman was stone. "Either way, I can see no other way to handle these Asha'man. Red sisters must bond them as Warders. If there is any way, I will be among the first, but it must be done." She sat there, calmly sipping her wine, and for a long time, Pevara could only stare at her in consternation. Nothing Tarna had said proved she was not Black Ajah, yet she could not distrust every sister unable to prove that. Well, she could and did, when it came to matters of the Black, but there were other matters she had to deal with. She was a Sitter, not simply a hunting dog. She had the White Tower to think of, and Aes Sedai far from the Tower. And the future.

dɪpɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪndə hɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd bɛl paʊtʃ, ʃi dʒɹu aʊɾ ə smɔl pis ə peɪpɝ ɹoʊld ɪndə ə θɪn tub. ɪt sim tə hɝ ðəɾ ɪt ʃəd ɡloʊ wɪð lɛɾɝz ə faɪɝ. soʊ fɑɹ, ʃi wɑz wʌn ə tu wɪmən ɪn ðə taʊɝ u nu wʌt wɑz ɹɪɾən ðɛɹ. ivən wʌns ʃi hæɾ ɪɾ aʊt, ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ hændɪŋ ɪt tə tɑɹnə. "ðɪs keɪm fɹəm wʌn ʌv əɹ eɪdʒəns ɪn kɛɹhin, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz sɛn baɪ tʌvaɪn ɡæzəl." tɑɹnəz aɪz dʒɝk tə pɛvɑɹəz feɪs ət ðə mɛnʃən ə tʌvaɪnz neɪm, ðən fɛl tə ɹiɾɪŋ əɡɛn.

Dipping her fingers into her embroidered belt pouch, she drew out a small piece of paper rolled into a thin tube. It seemed to her that it should glow with letters of fire. So far, she was one of two women in the Tower who knew what was written there. Even once she had it out, she hesitated before handing it to Tarna. "This came from one of our agents in Cairhien, but it was sent by Toveine Gazal." Tarna's eyes jerked to Pevara's face at the mention of Toveine's name, then fell to reading again.

hɝ stoʊni feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ivən æftɝ ʃi fɪnɪʃt ən lɛt ðə peɪpɝ ɹoʊl bæk ɪndə ə tub ɪn əɹ hænd.

Her stony face did not change even after she finished and let the paper roll back into a tube in her hand.

"ðɪs tʃeɪnʒəz nʌθɪŋ," ʃi sɛd flætli. koʊldli. "ɪɾ oʊnli meɪks wʌɾ aɪ sədʒɛs mɔɹ ɝdʒənt."

"This changes nothing," she said flatly. Coldly. "It only makes what I suggest more urgent."

"ɑn ðə kɑntʃɹɛɹi," pɛvɑɹə saɪd. "ðæt tʃeɪnʒəz ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪt tʃeɪnʒəz ðə hoʊl wɝld." tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi

"On the contrary," Pevara sighed. "That changes everything. It changes the whole world." CHAPTER 23

ɔɹnəməns ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz dʒʌst səfɪʃənli wɔɹmɝ ðən aʊtsaɪd tə pʊɾ ə mɪst ɑn ðə ɡlæs peɪnz sɛɾ ɪn ðə ɹɛd-peɪntəd keɪsməns, ən ðə ɡlæs kənteɪn bʌbəlz bɪsaɪdz, bʌt kædzueɪn stʊd piɹɪŋ aʊɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd si ðə dʒɹɪɹi lændskeɪp klɪɹli. ʃi kəd si wɪð mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf klɛɹəɾi, ɪn ɛni keɪs.

Ornaments The air in the room was just sufficiently warmer than outside to put a mist on the glass panes set in the red-painted casements, and the glass contained bubbles besides, but Cadsuane stood peering out as if she could see the dreary landscape clearly. She could see with more than enough clarity, in any case.

ə fju hæpləs foʊk, bʌndəld ən hæɾɪd ən oʊnli ʃeɪpləs skɝts əɹ bæɡi bɹitʃɪz dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃɪŋ mɛn fɹəm wɪmən, wɝ tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ ðə mʌɾi filz ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə mænɝ haʊs, səmtaɪmz stupɪŋ tə fil ə hændfʊl ə ðə sɔɪl. ɪt wəd nɑt bi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd bɪɡɪn ðɛɹ plaʊɪŋ ən mænɝɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli ðɛɹ ɪnspɛkʃən ɪndəkeɪɾəd ðə kʌmɪŋ ə spɹɪŋ ɛni taɪm sun. bɪɑn ðə filz, ðə fɔɹəst wɑz ɔl dɑɹk bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz əɡɛnst ə wɑʃɛdaʊt ɡɹeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ. ə ɡʊd koʊɾɪŋ ə snoʊ wʊɾə meɪd ðə vju mʌtʃ lɛs blik, bʌɾ ɪt snoʊd laɪtli ən sɛldəm hɪɹ, wɪð tʃɹeɪsəz ʌv wʌn fɔl ɹɛɹli læstɪŋ əntɪl ðə nɛkst. stɪl, ʃi kəd θɪŋk ə fju pleɪsəz bɛɾɝ fəɹ əɹ pɝpəsəz, wɪð ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə deɪz hɑɹd ɹaɪd tə ði ist. hu wəd θɪŋk tə lʊk ɪnsaɪd ðə bɔɹɾɝz ə tiɹ? hæd kənvɪnsɪŋ ðə bɔɪ tə steɪ hɪɹ bɪn tu izi, ðoʊ? wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi tɝn fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ, filɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns hæŋɪŋ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ sweɪ, ðə smɔl munz ən stɑɹz, bɝdz ən fɪʃ. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi əwɛɹ ə ðɛm, ʌv leɪt. əwɛɹ? fɔ! ʌv leɪt, ʃi hæd kənsɪɾɝd slipɪŋ wɪð əm ɪn pleɪs.

A few hapless folk, bundled and hatted and only shapeless skirts or baggy breeches distinguishing men from women, were trudging the muddy fields that surrounded the manor house, sometimes stooping to feel a handful of the soil. It would not be long before they could begin their plowing and manuring, but only their inspection indicated the coming of spring any time soon. Beyond the fields, the forest was all dark bare branches against a washedout gray morning sky. A good coating of snow would have made the view much less bleak, but it snowed lightly and seldom here, with traces of one fall rarely lasting until the next. Still, she could think of few places better for her purposes, with the Spine of the World little more than a day's hard ride to the east. Who would think to look inside the borders of Tear? Had convincing the boy to stay here been too easy, though? With a sigh, she turned from the window, feeling the golden ornaments hanging in her hair sway, the small moons and stars, birds and fish. She was very aware of them, of late. Aware? Phaw! Of late, she had considered sleeping with them in place.

ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɑz lɑɹdʒ bʌt nɑɾ ɔɹneɪt, laɪk ðə mænɝ haʊs ɪtsɛlf, wɪð kɔɹnɪsəz ə kɑɹvd wʊd, peɪntəd ɹɛd. ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ wɑz bɹaɪt wɪð peɪn bʌt nɑɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɪldɪŋ, ðə tu lɔŋ faɪɝpleɪsəz pleɪn stoʊn ɪf wɛl meɪd, ði ændaɪɝənz stɝɾi ɹɔt mɛɾəl meɪd fəɹ lɔŋ sɝvəs ɹæðɝ ðən əpɪɹənsəz. ðə faɪɝz ɑn ðə hɑɹθs wɝ smɔl, əɾ əɹ ɪnsɪstəns, ðə fleɪmz flɪkɝɪŋ loʊ ɑn hæf-kənsum splɪts, bʌɾ iðɝ wɑz ɪnʌf tə wɔɹm əɹ hænz, wɪtʃ wɑz ɔl ʃi wɑntəd. lɛf tə hɪz oʊn dɪvaɪsəz, ælɡɝɪn wʊɾə sɝaʊndəɾ əɹ wɪð bleɪzɪŋ wɔɹmθ ən smʌðɝɾ əɹ ɪn sɝvəns, fju əz i stɪl ɛmplɔɪd. ə lɛsɝ lɔɹɾ ə ðə lænd, hi wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm wɛlθi, jɛɾ i peɪɾ ɪz dɛts ɪn lɛɾɝ ən spɪɹət, ivən wən moʊst ʌðɝ mɛn wʊɾə sin kwaɪt ðə ɹɪvɝs ʌv ə dɛt. ði ənkɑɹv dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl kɹikt oʊpən - moʊst ʌv ælɡɝɪnz sɝvəns wɝ nɪɹli əz oʊld əz hi, ən ðoʊ ðeɪ kɛpt ɛvɹiθɪŋ dʌstɪɾ ən nit, ðə læmps tɑpt wɪð ɔɪl ən ðə wɪks tʃɹɪmd, hɪnʒɪz ɪn ðə mænɝ sim tə ɪskeɪp ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɔɪlɪŋ - ðə dɔɹ kɹikt oʊpən tə ədmɪt vɛɹɪn, stɪl dʒɹɛs fəɹ ə dʒɝni ɪn sɪmpəl bɹaʊn wʊl wɪð dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən kæɹiɪŋ əɹ kloʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹm, stɪl pæɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛɹ ɪndə pleɪs.

The sitting room was large but not ornate, like the manor house itself, with cornices of carved wood, painted red. The furniture was bright with paint but not a touch of gilding, the two long fireplaces plain stone if well made, the andirons sturdy wrought metal made for long service rather than appearances. The fires on the hearths were small, at her insistence, the flames flickering low on half-consumed splits, but either was enough to warm her hands, which was all she wanted. Left to his own devices, Algarin would have surrounded her with blazing warmth and smothered her in servants, few as he still employed. A lesser Lord of the Land, he was far from wealthy, yet he paid his debts in letter and spirit, even when most other men would have seen quite the reverse of a debt. The uncarved door to the hall creaked open - most of Algarin's servants were nearly as old as he, and though they kept everything dusted and neat, the lamps topped with oil and the wicks trimmed, hinges in the manor seemed to escape regular oiling - the door creaked open to admit Verin, still dressed for a journey in simple brown wool with divided skirts and carrying her cloak over her arm, still patting her gray-streaked hair into place.

ðə staʊt lɪɾəl sɪstɝz skwɛɹ feɪs wɔɹ ə vɛkst ɪkspɹɛʃən, ən ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "wɛl, ðə si foʊk ɑɹ dɪlɪvɝd tə tɛɹ, kædzueɪn. aɪ dɪdnt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðə stoʊn, bʌɾ aɪ hɝd ðət haɪ lɔɹɾ əstɔɹəl stɑp kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz kɹikɪŋ dʒɔɪns ən mʌstɝɾ ɪnsaɪd wɪð dɑɹlɪn. huɾ əv θɔɾ əstɔɹəl wəd stɝ hɪmsɛlf, ən ɑn dɑɹlɪnz saɪd? ðə stʃɹits ɑɹ fʊl ʌv ɑɹmmɪn, moʊst ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk ən pɪkɪŋ faɪts wɪð itʃ ʌðɝ wən ðəɹ nɑt faɪɾɪŋ æθɑn maɪɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ əz mɛni si foʊk ɪn ðə sɪɾi əz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls pʊt təɡɛðɝ. hɑɹɪn wɑz əɡæst. ʃi wɛn ɹʌʃɪŋ aʊt tə ðə ʃɪps əz sun əz ʃi kəd haɪɝ ə boʊt, ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə bi dɪklɛɹd mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps ən sɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ tə ɹaɪts. ðəɹ simz noʊ daʊt ðət nɛstə dɪn ɹiz ɪz dɛd." kædzueɪn wɑz kɑntɛn tə lɛt ðə ɹaʊn lɪɾəl wʊmən tʃæɾɝ ɑn.

The stout little sister's square face wore a vexed expression, and she was shaking her head. "Well, the Sea Folk are delivered to Tear, Cadsuane. I didn't go near the Stone, but I heard that High Lord Astoril stopped complaining about his creaking joints and mustered inside with Darlin. Who'd have thought Astoril would stir himself, and on Darlin's side? The streets are full of armsmen, most getting drunk and picking fights with each other when they're not fighting Atha'an Miere. There are as many Sea Folk in the city as everyone else put together. Harine was aghast. She went rushing out to the ships as soon as she could hire a boat, expecting to be declared Mistress of the Ships and set everything to rights. There seems no doubt that Nesta din Reas is dead." Cadsuane was content to let the round little woman chatter on.

vɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt nɪɹli soʊ veɪɡ əz ʃi pɹitɛndəd. səm bɹaʊnz ɹɪli wɝ keɪpəbəl ə tʃɹɪpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ oʊn fit fɹəm nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt vɛɹɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u wɔɹ ən əsum kloʊk ʌv ənwɝldlinəs. ʃi sim tə bɪliv ðət kædzueɪn æksɛptɪd ðə kloʊk fəɹ ɹiæləɾi, jɛɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə pɔɪn tə bi meɪd, ʃi wəd meɪk ɪt. ən wʌt ʃi lɛft aʊt maɪt bi ɹɪvilɪŋ, tu. kædzueɪn wɑz lɛs ʃʊɹ ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ ðən ʃi maɪɾ əv wɪʃt. ənsɝɾənti wɑz ə fækt ə laɪf, bʌt ʃi wɑz ənsɝɾən əbaʊɾ ɪntaɪɝli tu mɛni θɪŋz tə sut hɝ.

Verin was not nearly so vague as she pretended. Some Browns really were capable of tripping over their own feet from not noticing them, but Verin was one of those who wore an assumed cloak of unworldliness. She seemed to believe that Cadsuane accepted the cloak for reality, yet if there was a point to be made, she would make it. And what she left out might be revealing, too. Cadsuane was less sure of the other sister than she might have wished. Uncertainty was a fact of life, but she was uncertain about entirely too many things to suit her.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, mɪn mʌst əv bɪn lɪsnɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ, ən ðət jʌŋ wʊmən hæd lɪɾəl peɪʃəns. "aɪ toʊl hɑɹɪn ɪt wʊdn bi laɪk ðæt," ʃi pɹətɛstəd, bɝstɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "aɪ toʊld əɹ ʃid bi pʌnɪʃt fəɹ ðə bɑɹɡən ʃi meɪd wɪð ɹænd. oʊnli æftɝ ðət wɪl ʃi bɪkʌm mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, ən aɪ kæn seɪ ɪf ɪɾəl bi tɛn deɪz fɹəm naʊ əɹ tɛn jɪɹz." slɪm ən pɹɪɾi, ən tɔl ɪn əɹ ɹɛd-hil buts, wɪð dɑɹk ɹɪŋləts hæŋɪŋ tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, mɪn hæɾ ə loʊ wʊmənli vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ ə bɔɪz ɹɛd koʊɾ ən blu bɹitʃɪz. ðə koʊt wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð kʌlɝfəl flaʊɝz ɑn ðə ləpɛlz ən ʌp ðə slivz, ən ðə bɹitʃɪz ɪn bænz daʊn ði aʊtsaɪdz ə ðə lɛɡz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz.

Unfortunately, Min must have been listening at the door, and that young woman had little patience. "I told Harine it wouldn't be like that," she protested, bursting into the room. "I told her she'd be punished for the bargain she made with Rand. Only after that will she become Mistress of the Ships, and I can't say if it will be ten days from now or ten years." Slim and pretty, and tall in her red-heeled boots, with dark ringlets hanging to her shoulders, Min had a low womanly voice, but she wore a boy's red coat and blue breeches. The coat was embroidered with colorful flowers on the lapels and up the sleeves, and the breeches in bands down the outsides of the legs, but they were still coat and breeches.

"ju meɪ kʌm ɪn, mɪn," kædzueɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. ɪt wɑz ə toʊn ðət juʒəwəli meɪd pipəl sɪɾ ʌp ən teɪk noʊɾəs. ðoʊz u nu hɝ əɾ ɔl, ɛniweɪ. spɑts ə kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn mɪnz tʃiks. "ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs əz ɔlɹɛɾi lɝn ɔl ʃiz ɡoʊɪŋ tə fɹəm jəɹ vjuɪŋ, aɪ fɪɹ. bʌt fɹəm jəɹ ɝdʒənsi, pɝhæps juv ɹɛd sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz ɔʊɹəz ən wɪʃ tə tɛl mi wʌt jə sɔ?" ðə ɡɝlz pəkjuljɝ əbɪləɾi hæd pɹuv hɛlpfəl ɪn ðə pæst ən daʊtləs kəɾ əɡɛn. pɝhæps. əz fɑɹ əz kædzueɪn kəd tɛl, ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪ əbaʊt wʌt ʃi sɔ ɪn ði ɪmədʒəz ən ɔʊɹəz ðət ʃi pɝsiv floʊɾɪŋ ɝaʊn pipəl, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ, iðɝ. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli nɑt wən ɪt keɪm tə ðə wʌn pɝsən kædzueɪn wʊɾə laɪk tə noʊ əbaʊɾ əbʌv ɔl ʌðɝz.

"You may come in, Min," Cadsuane said quietly. It was a tone that usually made people sit up and take notice. Those who knew her at all, anyway. Spots of color appeared in Min's cheeks. "The Wavemistress has already learned all she is going to from your viewing, I fear. But from your urgency, perhaps you've read someone else's auras and wish to tell me what you saw?" The girl's peculiar ability had proved helpful in the past and doubtless could again. Perhaps. As far as Cadsuane could tell, she did not lie about what she saw in the images and auras that she perceived floating around people, but she was not always forthcoming, either. Particularly not when it came to the one person Cadsuane would have liked to know about above all others.

ɹɛd tʃiks əɹ noʊ ɹɛd tʃiks, mɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ tʃɪn stʌbɝnli. ʃi hæd tʃeɪnʒd sɪns ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, əɹ pɝhæps ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn ɝliɝ, bʌɾ iðɝ weɪ, ðə tʃeɪnʒ wɑz nɑt fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ. "ɹænd wɑns jə tə kʌm si hɪm. hi sɛd tə æsk, soʊ jə nidnt ɡɛt snɪpi oʊvɝ ɪt." kædzueɪn mɪɹli lʊkt əɾ əɹ ən lɛt ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃ. snɪpi? dɛfənətli nɑt fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ.

Red cheeks or no red cheeks, Min raised her chin stubbornly. She had changed since Shadar Logoth, or perhaps it had begun earlier, but either way, the change was not for the better. "Rand wants you to come see him. He said to ask, so you needn't get snippy over it." Cadsuane merely looked at her and let the silence stretch. Snippy? Definitely not for the better.

"tɛl ɪm əl kʌm wən aɪm eɪbəl," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "kloʊz ðə dɔɹ fɝmli bɪhaɪn ju, mɪn." ðə jʌŋ wʊmən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əz ɪf tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, bʌɾ ət list ʃi ɹɪteɪn sɛns ɪnʌf tə liv ɪɾ ənsɛd. ʃi ivən meɪɾ ə pæsəbəl kɝtsi, ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðoʊz ɹɪdɪkjələs buts, ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ fɝmli bɪhaɪn hɝ. dʒʌs bɛɹli ʃɔɹɾ ə slæmɪŋ ɪt, ɪn fækt.

"Tell him I will come when I am able," she said finally. "Close the door firmly behind you, Min." The young woman opened her mouth as if to say something more, but at least she retained sense enough to leave it unsaid. She even made a passable curtsy, in spite of those ridiculous boots, and shut the door firmly behind her. Just barely short of slamming it, in fact.

vɛɹɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛn, ɡɪvɪŋ ə læf ðət saʊndəɾ oʊnli slaɪtli əmjuzd. "ʃiz ɪn lʌv wɪð ðə jʌŋ mæn, kædzueɪn, ən ʃiz tʌkt əɹ hɑɹɾ ɪn ɪz pɑkət. ʃɪl fɑloʊ ðət bɪfɔɹ əɹ hɛd, wʌtɛvɝ jə seɪ əɹ du. aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz əfɹeɪɾ i ɔlmoʊs daɪɾ ɑn hɝ, ən jə noʊ haʊ ðət kən meɪk ə wʊmən dɪtɝmən tə hæŋ ɑn."

Verin shook her head again, giving a laugh that sounded only slightly amused. "She's in love with the young man, Cadsuane, and she's tucked her heart in his pocket. She'll follow that before her head, whatever you say or do. I think she's afraid he almost died on her, and you know how that can make a woman determined to hang on."

kædzueɪnz lɪps θɪnd. vɛɹɪn nu mɔɹ əbaʊt ðət sɔɹɾ ə ɹileɪʃənz wɪð mɛn ðən ʃi dɪd -  ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪlivd ɪn ɪndʌlʒɪŋ wɪð əɹ oʊn wɔɹɾɝz, əz səm ɡɹinz dɪd, ən ʌðɝ mɛn hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən - bʌt ðə bɹaʊn hæd hɪt kloʊz tə ə tʃɹuθ wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ. ət list, kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ nu mɪn wɑz bɑndəd tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ. ʃi hɝsɛlf oʊnli nu kəz ðə ɡɝl hæd lɛt tu mʌtʃ slɪp ɪn ə kɛɹləs moʊmənt. ivən ðə taɪɾəst mʌsəl ɪvɛntʃəwəli jildəɾ ɪts mit wʌns jə ɡɑt ðət fɝst smɔl kɹæk ɪn ðə ʃɛl. səmtaɪmz ɪt ɡeɪv ʌp ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd pɝl, əz wɛl. jɛs, mɪn wəd wɑnə kip ðə læɾ əlaɪv wɛðɝ ʃi lʌvd ɪm əɹ nɑt, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən kædzueɪn dɪd.

Cadsuane's lips thinned. Verin knew more about that sort of relations with men than she did -  she had never believed in indulging with her own Warders, as some Greens did, and other men had always been out of the question - but the Brown had hit close to a truth without knowing. At least, Cadsuane did not think the other sister knew Min was bonded to the alThor boy. She herself only knew because the girl had let too much slip in a careless moment. Even the tightest mussel eventually yielded its meat once you got that first small crack in the shell. Sometimes it gave up an unexpected pearl, as well. Yes, Min would want to keep the lad alive whether she loved him or not, but no more than Cadsuane did.

dʒɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɑn ðə tɔl bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ, vɛɹɪn muv tə ðə nɪɹəs faɪɝpleɪs ən stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ əɹ hænz tə wɔɹm əm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə loʊ fleɪmz. jə kəd nɑt seɪ ðət vɛɹɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd, bʌt ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ɡɹeɪsfəl ðən əɹ bʌlk sədʒɛstəd. haʊ mʌtʃ ə hɝ wɑz dɪsɛpʃən? ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪd bɪhaɪn vɛɹiəs mæsks, oʊvɝ taɪm. ɪt bɪkeɪm hæbəɾ æftɝ ə waɪl. "aɪ bɪliv ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən ɪn tiɹ meɪ bi ɹizɑlv pisfəli jɛt," ʃi sɛd, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə faɪɝ. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. əɹ wɑntəd kædzueɪn tə θɪŋk ɪt. "hɝn ən sɪmɑn ɑɹ ɡɹoʊɪŋ kwaɪt dɛspɹɪt, əfɹeɪd ði ʌðɝ haɪ lɔɹdz wɪl ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ɪljən ən tʃɹæp əm ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪ meɪ bi əmɛnəbəl tə æksɛptɪŋ dɑɹlɪn, ɡɪvən ðɛɹ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪsəz. ɪstændə ɪz meɪɾ ə stɝnɝ stʌf, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi kən bi kənvɪns ðɛɹz ædvæntɪdʒ fəɹ əɹ ɪn ɪt - "

Draping her cloak on the tall back of a chair, Verin moved to the nearest fireplace and stretched out her hands to warm them in front of the low flames. You could not say that Verin glided, but she was more graceful than her bulk suggested. How much of her was deception? Every Aes Sedai hid behind various masks, over time. It became habit after a while. "I believe the situation in Tear may be resolved peacefully yet," she said, peering into the fire. She might have been talking to herself. Or wanted Cadsuane to think it. "Hearne and Simaan are growing quite desperate, afraid the other High Lords will return from Illian and trap them in the city. They may be amenable to accepting Darlin, given their other choices. Estanda is made of sterner stuff, but if she can be convinced there's advantage for her in it - "

"aɪ toʊl jə nɑt tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðɛm," kædzueɪn bɹoʊk ɪn stɝnli.

"I told you not to go near them," Cadsuane broke in sternly.

ðə staʊt wʊmən blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "aɪ dɪdnt. ðə stʃɹits ɑɹ ɔlweɪz fʊl ə ɹumɝz, ən aɪ də noʊ haʊ tə ɹumɝz təɡɛðɝ ən sɪft aʊɾ ə lɪɾəl tʃɹuθ. aɪ dɪd si ɑlɑnə ən ɹæfɛlə, bʌɾ aɪ dʌk bɪhaɪn ə fɛloʊ hɔkɪŋ mit paɪz fɹəm ə bæɹoʊ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɔ mi. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðeɪ dɪdnt." ʃi pɔzd, klɪɹli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ kædzueɪn tə ɪkspleɪn waɪ ʃi hæd bɪn toʊl tə əvɔɪd ðə sɪstɝz əz wɛl.

The stout woman blinked at her in surprise. "I didn't. The streets are always full of rumors, and I do know how to rumors together and sift out a little truth. I did see Alanna and Rafela, but I ducked behind a fellow hawking meat pies from a barrow before they saw me. I'm sure they didn't." She paused, clearly waiting for Cadsuane to explain why she had been told to avoid the sisters as well.

"aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ tə ðə bɔɪ naʊ, vɛn," kædzueɪn sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. ðət wɑz ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð əɡɹiɪŋ tə ædvaɪz sʌmwʌn. ivən wən jə mænədʒ tə sɛɾ ɔl ðə kəndɪʃənz jə kəd wɪʃ fəɹ - moʊst ə ðɛm, ɛniweɪ - jə stɪl hæd tə kʌm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ wən ðeɪ kɔld. ɪvɛntʃəwəli. bʌɾ ɪt dɪd ɡɪv əɹ ə ɹizən tə ɪveɪd vɛɹɪnz kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ði ænsɝ wɑz sɪmpəl. ɪf jə tʃɹaɪd tə sɑlv ɛvɹi pɹɑbləm jɝsɛlf, jə ɛndəd baɪ sɑlvɪŋ nʌn. ən wɪð səm pɹɑbləmz, haʊ ðeɪ wɝ sɑlvd ɹɪli dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn. bʌt nɑɾ ænsɝɪŋ lɛf vɛɹɪn wɪð ə pʌzəl tə pɑndɝ, ə lɪɾəl bʌɾɝ fəɹ əɹ pɔz. wən kædzueɪn wɑz ənʃʊɹ ə sʌmwʌn, ʃi wɑntəɾ əm ənʃʊɹ ə hɝ, tu.

"I have to go to the boy now, Venn," Cadsuane said instead. That was the trouble with agreeing to advise someone. Even when you managed to set all the conditions you could wish for - most of them, anyway - you still had to come sooner or later when they called. Eventually. But it did give her a reason to evade Verin's curiosity. The answer was simple. If you tried to solve every problem yourself, you ended by solving none. And with some problems, how they were solved really did not matter in the long run. But not answering left Verin with a puzzle to ponder, a little butter for her paws. When Cadsuane was unsure of someone, she wanted them unsure of her, too.

vɛɹɪn ɡæðɝɾ ʌp əɹ kloʊk ən lɛf ðə ɹum wɪð hɝ. dɪd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən min tə əkʌmpəni hɝ? bʌɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ðeɪ ɪnkaʊntɝd nɛsun wɔkɪŋ bɹɪskli daʊn ðə hɔl.

Verin gathered up her cloak and left the room with her. Did the other woman mean to accompany her? But outside the sitting room, they encountered Nesune walking briskly down the hall.

ʃi keɪm tə ə sʌɾən hɔlt. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ə pipəl hæɾ ɛvɝ mænədʒ tə ɪɡnɔɹ kædzueɪn, jɛt nɛsun dɪɾ ə kɹɛɾəbəl dʒɑb, hɝ nɪɹli blæk aɪz lætʃɪŋ ɑn tə vɛɹɪn.

She came to a sudden halt. No more than a handful of people had ever managed to ignore Cadsuane, yet Nesune did a credible job, her nearly black eyes latching on to Verin.

"jɔɹ bæk ðɛn, ɑɹ ju?" ðə bɛst ə bɹaʊnz dɪɾ əv ə weɪ ʌv steɪɾɪŋ ði ɑbviəs. "ju ɹoʊɾ ə peɪpɝ ɑn ænəməlz ə ðə dʒɹaʊn lænz, əz aɪ ɹikɔl." wɪtʃ mɛn ðət vɛɹɪn hæd; nɛsun ɹɪkɔld ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin - ə jusfəl skɪl, ɪf kædzueɪn hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪnʌf ə hɝ tə meɪk jus ʌv ɪt. "lɔɹɾ ælɡɝɪn ʃoʊd mi ðə skɪn ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ sneɪk i kleɪmz keɪm fɹəm ðə dʒɹaʊn lænz, bʌɾ aɪm kənvɪnst ɪts ðə seɪm əz aɪ əbzɝvd. . . ." vɛɹɪn ɡlæns hɛlpləsli ət kædzueɪn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əz ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən dʒɹu hɝ əweɪ baɪ hɝ sliv, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ θɹi stɛps əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ʃi wɑz dip ɪn dɪskʌʃən oʊvɝ ðɪs ful sneɪk.

"You're back then, are you?" The best of Browns did have a way of stating the obvious. "You wrote a paper on animals of the Drowned Lands, as I recall." Which meant that Verin had; Nesune recalled everything she had ever seen - a useful skill, if Cadsuane had been sure enough of her to make use of it. "Lord Algarin showed me the skin of a large snake he claims came from the Drowned Lands, but I'm convinced it is the same as I observed. . . ." Verin glanced helplessly at Cadsuane over her shoulder as the taller woman drew her away by her sleeve, but before they were three steps along the corridor, she was deep in discussion over this fool snake.

ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl saɪt, ən tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ɪn ə weɪ. nɛsun wɑz lɔɪəl tə ɪleɪɾə, əɹ hæd bɪn, waɪl vɛɹɪn wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz u wɑntəd tə pʊl ɪleɪɾə daʊn. əɹ hæd bɪn. naʊ ðeɪ tɔkt eɪmiəbli əbaʊt sneɪks. ðət boʊθ hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ kəd bi leɪd tə hɪz biɪŋ tɑvɝən, waɪndɪŋ ðə pæɾɝn ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf ʌnkɑnʃəsli, bʌt wɑz ðəɾ oʊθ səfɪʃən tə meɪk əm ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛɹ ɑpəzɪʃən oʊvɝ u hɛl ði æmɪɝlɪn sit? əɹ wɝ ðeɪ əfɛktəd baɪ hævɪŋ ə tɑvɝən ɪn kloʊs pɹɑksɪməɾi? ʃi wʊɾə laɪk vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə noʊ ðæt. nʌn ə hɝ ɔɹnəməns pɹətɛktəɾ əɡɛns tɑvɝən. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tu ʌv ðə fɪʃ ən wʌn ə ðə munz dɪd, bʌɾ ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðeɪ dɪd ðæt. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn əz sɪmpəl əz vɛɹɪn ən nɛsun boʊθ biɪŋ bɹaʊn. bɹaʊnz kəd fɝɡɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls wən ðeɪ sɛɾəld tə stʌɾi sʌmθɪŋ. sneɪks. fɔ! ðə smɔl ɔɹnəməns sweɪɾ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, hævɪŋ ðə tu ɹɪsiɾɪŋ bɹaʊnz bɪhaɪnd. wʌd ðə bɔɪ wɑnt? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ laɪk biɪŋ ən ædvaɪzɝ, nɛsəsɛɹi əɹ nɑt.

It was a remarkable sight, and troubling in a way. Nesune was loyal to Elaida, or had been, while Verin was one of those who wanted to pull Elaida down. Or had been. Now they talked amiably about snakes. That both had sworn fealty to the al'Thor boy could be laid to his being ta'veren, winding the Pattern around himself unconsciously, but was that oath sufficient to make them ignore their opposition over who held the Amyrlin Seat? Or were they affected by having a ta'veren in close proximity? She would have liked very much to know that. None of her ornaments protected against ta'veren. Of course, she did not know what two of the fish and one of the moons did, but it seemed unlikely they did that. It could have been as simple as Verin and Nesune both being Brown. Browns could forget everything else when they settled to study something. Snakes. Phaw! The small ornaments swayed as she shook her head before turning away, having the two receding Browns behind. What did the boy want? She had never liked being an advisor, necessary or not.

dʒɹæfs əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ɹɪpəl ðə fju tæpəstʃɹiz ɑn ðə wɔlz, ɔl ɪn oʊl staɪlz ən ʃoʊɪŋ ðə wɛɹ ə hævɪŋ bɪn teɪkən daʊn ən ɹihʌŋ mɛni taɪmz. ðə mænɝ haʊs hæd ɡɹoʊn laɪk ə ɹæmblɪŋ fɑɹmhaʊs ɹæðɝ ðən biɪŋ bɪlt lɑɹdʒ, wɪð ədɪʃənz æɾəd wɛnɛvɝ ðə fæmliz fɔɹtʃənz ən nʌmbɝz wækst. haʊs pɛndəloʊn hæd nɛvɝ bɪn wɛlθi, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn taɪmz ðeɪ wɝ numɝəs. ðə ɹɪzʌls ʃoʊɾ ɪn mɔɹ ðən wɔɹn, oʊldfɑʃənd wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz. ðə kɔɹnɪsəz wɝ bɹaɪtli peɪntəd, ɹɛɾ əɹ blu əɹ jɛloʊ, bʌt ðə hɔlweɪz vɛɹiɾ ɪn wɪdθ ən haɪt, ən səmtaɪmz mɛɾ əɾ ə slaɪt skju. wɪndoʊz ðət wʌns hæd lʊk tə ðə filz naʊ lʊk daʊn ɑn kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz, juʒəwəli bɛɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju bɛntʃɪz ən pleɪs pjʊɹli tə pɹəvaɪd laɪt. səmtaɪmz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɔɪs ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹəm hɪɹ tə ðəɹ ɪksɛp tə teɪk ə ɹuf kɑləneɪɾ oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz kɔɹtʃjɑɹdz. ðə kɑləmz wɝ wʊɾən mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt, ðoʊ bɹeɪvli peɪntəɾ ivən wɛɹ nɑt kɑɹvd.

Drafts along the corridors rippled the few tapestries on the walls, all in old styles and showing the wear of having been taken down and rehung many times. The manor house had grown like a rambling farmhouse rather than being built large, with additions added whenever the family's fortunes and numbers waxed. House Pendaloan had never been wealthy, but there had been times they were numerous. The results showed in more than worn, oldfashioned wall hangings. The cornices were brightly painted, red or blue or yellow, but the hallways varied in width and height, and sometimes met at a slight skew. Windows that once had looked to the fields now looked down on courtyards, usually bare except for a few benches and placed purely to provide light. Sometimes there was no choice in getting from here to there except to take a roofed colonnade overlooking one of those courtyards. The columns were wooden more often than not, though bravely painted even where not carved.

ɑn wʌn ə ðoʊz wɔkweɪz, wɪð fæt ɡɹin kɑləmz, tu sɪstɝz wɝ stændɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ði æktɪvəɾi ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd bɪloʊ. ət list, ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wən kædzueɪn oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɑləneɪd. bɛldaɪn sɔ hɝ stɛp aʊt, ən stɪfənd, twɪtʃɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ʃi hæd wɔɹn fjuɝ ðən faɪv jɪɹz. pɹɪɾi, wɪð əɹ haɪ tʃikboʊnz ən ə slaɪt tɪl tə hɝ bɹaʊn aɪz, ʃi hæd nɑt jɛɾ ətʃivd eɪɡləsnəs, ən lʊk jʌŋɡɝ ðən mɪn, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wən ʃi ʃɑt kædzueɪn ə fɹɔsti stɛɹ ən hɝid fɹəm ðə kɑləneɪɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən.

On one of those walkways, with fat green columns, two sisters were standing together watching the activity in the courtyard below. At least, they were watching together when Cadsuane opened the door to the colonnade. Beldeine saw her step out, and stiffened, twitching at the green-fringed shawl she had worn fewer than five years. Pretty, with her high cheekbones and a slight tilt to her brown eyes, she had not yet achieved agelessness, and looked younger than Min, particularly when she shot Cadsuane a frosty stare and hurried from the colonnade in the other direction.

mɛɹaɪs, hɝ kəmpænjən, smaɪld æftɝ əɹ ɪn əmjuzmənt, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ oʊn ɡɹin-fɹɪnd ʃɔl slaɪtli. tɔl ən juʒəwəli kwaɪt sɪɹiəs, wɪð əɹ hɛɹ dʒɹɔn bæk taɪtli fɹəm əɹ peɪl feɪs, mɛɹaɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən u smaɪld ɔfən. "bɛldaɪn, ʃiz bɪkʌmɪŋ kənsɝn ðət ʃiz noʊ wɔɹɾɝ jɛt," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ði æksɛns ə tæɹɑbən əz kædzueɪn stɑp bɪsaɪd hɝ, ðoʊ hɝ blu aɪz ɹɪtɝn tə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. "ʃi simz tə bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ən æʃə'-mæn, ɪf ʃi kən faɪnd wʌn. aɪ toʊld əɹ tə tɔk tə deɪdʒiən.

Merise, her companion, smiled after her in amusement, shifting her own green-fringed shawl slightly. Tall and usually quite serious, with her hair drawn back tightly from her pale face, Merise was not a woman who smiled often. "Beldeine, she is becoming concerned that she has no Warder yet," she said in the accents of Tarabon as Cadsuane stopped beside her, though her blue eyes returned to the courtyard. "She seems to be considering an Asha'-man, if she can find one. I told her to talk to Daigian.

ɪf ɪt dʌz nɑt hɛlp hɝ, ɪɾəl hɛlp deɪdʒiən."

If it does not help her, it will help Daigian."
