ɔl ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz ðeɪ hæd wɪð əm wɝ ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn-peɪv jɑɹd, ɪn ðɛɹ ʃɝtslivz dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld, moʊst siɾəd ɑn peɪntəd wʊɾən bɛntʃɪz wɑtʃɪŋ tu ʌv ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ wɝk wɪð wʊɾən pɹæktəs sɔɹdz. dʒɑhɹ, wʌn ə mɛɹaɪsəz θɹi, wɑz ə pɹɪɾi, sʌn-dɑɹk jʌŋ mæn. ðə sɪlvɝ bɛlz fæsən tə ði ɛnz ə hɪz tu lɔŋ bɹeɪdz tʃaɪmd wɪð ðə fjʊɹi ʌv ɪz ətæk. hi muv laɪk ə stʃɹaɪkɪŋ blækləns. nɑɾ ə bɹɛθ ə bɹiz stɝd, bʌt ði eɪt-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ, laɪk ə ɡoʊldən kʌmpəs ɹoʊz, sim tə ʃɪft əɡɛns kædzueɪnz hɛɹ. hæɾ ɪt bɪn hɛld ɪn əɹ hænd, ʃi cʊɾə fɛlt ɪt vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ klɪɹli. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi nu ðət dʒɑhɹ wɑz ən æʃəmən, ən ðə stɑɹ wəd nɑɾ əv pɔɪntəɾ ɪm aʊt, mɪɹli toʊld əɹ ðəɾ ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl wɑz nɪɹbaɪ. ðə mɔɹ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ðə stɑɹ kwɪvɝd, ʃi hæd lɝnd. dʒɑhɹz əpoʊnənt, ə vɛɹi tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd fɛloʊ wɪð ə stoʊn feɪs ən ə bɹeɪɾɪd lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ɝaʊn ɪz ɡɹeɪɪŋ tɛmpəlz tə hoʊl bæk ʃoʊldɝ-lɛŋθ hɛɹ, wɑz nɑt ðə sɛkən æʃəmən daʊn ðɛɹ, bʌɾ i wɑz əz dɛdli ɪn ɪz oʊn weɪ. læn dɪd nɑt ɹɪli sim tə muv ðət fæst, bʌɾ i . . . floʊd. hɪz bleɪɾ ə bʌndəld læθs wɑz ɔlweɪz ðəɹ tə dɪflɛk dʒɑhɹz, ɔlweɪz muvɪŋ ðə jʌŋɡɝ mæn dʒʌst ə tʌtʃ mɔɹ aʊɾ ə hɪz laɪn. sʌɾənli, lænz wʊɾən bleɪd stʃɹʌk dʒɑhɹz saɪd wɪð ə ɹisaʊndɪŋ kɹæk, ə kɪlɪŋ bloʊ ɡɪvən wɪð stil. waɪl ðə jʌŋɡɝ mæn wɑz stɪl flɪntʃɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɔɹs ə ðə stʃɹaɪk, læn floʊd bæk ɪndə ə ɹɛɾi stæns, lɔŋ bleɪɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. nɛθən, ənʌðɝ ə mɛɹaɪsəz, ɹoʊz tə hɪz fit, ə lin fɛloʊ wɪð wɪŋz ʌv waɪɾ əɾ ɪz tɛmpəlz ən tɔl, ɪf stɪl ə hæn əɹ mɔɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən læn. dʒɑhɹ weɪvd ɪm əweɪ ən ɹeɪzd ɪz pɹæktəs bleɪɾ əɡɛn, laʊdli dɪmændɪŋ ənʌðɝ ɡoʊ.

All of the Warders they had with them were gathered in the stone-paved yard, in their shirtsleeves despite the cold, most seated on painted wooden benches watching two of their number work with wooden practice swords. Jahar, one of Merise's three, was a pretty, sun-dark young man. The silver bells fastened to the ends of his two long braids chimed with the fury of his attack. He moved like a striking blacklance. Not a breath of breeze stirred, but the eight-pointed star, like a golden compass rose, seemed to shift against Cadsuane's hair. Had it been held in her hand, she could have felt it vibrating clearly. But then, she already knew that Jahar was an Asha'man, and the star would not have pointed him out, merely told her that a man who could channel was nearby. The more men who could channel, the harder the star quivered, she had learned. Jahar's opponent, a very tall, broad-shouldered fellow with a stone face and a braided leather cord around his graying temples to hold back shoulder-length hair, was not the second Asha'man down there, but he was as deadly in his own way. Lan did not really seem to move that fast, but he . . . flowed. His blade of bundled laths was always there to deflect Jahar's, always moving the younger man just a touch more out of his line. Suddenly, Lan's wooden blade struck Jahar's side with a resounding crack, a killing blow given with steel. While the younger man was still flinching from the force of the strike, Lan flowed back into a ready stance, long blade upright in his hands. Nethan, another of Merise's, rose to his feet, a lean fellow with wings of white at his temples and tall, if still a hand or more shorter than Lan. Jahar waved him away and raised his practice blade again, loudly demanding another go.

"ɪz deɪdʒiən stɪl bɛɹɪŋ ʌp?" kædzueɪn æskt.

"Is Daigian still bearing up?" Cadsuane asked.

"bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd," mɛɹaɪs ədmɪɾəd. "ʃi steɪz ɪn əɹ ɹum tu mʌtʃ, bʌt ʃi kips əɹ wipɪŋ pɹaɪvət." hɝ ɡeɪz ʃɪftəd fɹəm ðə mɛn dænsɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz tə ə ɡɹin-peɪntəd bɛntʃ wɛɹ vɛɹɪnz stɑki ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd toʊmɑs sæt nɛks tə ə ɡɹɪzəl fɛloʊ wɪð oʊnli ə fɹɪnʒ ʌv waɪt hɛɹ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ. "dɑɹnɝ, hi wɑntəd tə tʃɹaɪ hɪz hilɪŋ ɑn hɝ, bʌt deɪdʒiən ɹəfjuzd. ʃi meɪ nɛvɝ əv hæɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ʃi noʊz ðət ðə ɡɹivɪŋ oʊvɝ ə dɛd wɔɹɾɝ ɪz pɑɹɾ ə ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ hɪm. aɪm sɝpɹaɪz ðət kɔɹəl wəd kənsɪɾɝ əlaʊɪŋ ɪt."

"Better than I expected," Merise admitted. "She stays in her room too much, but she keeps her weeping private." Her gaze shifted from the men dancing their swords to a green-painted bench where Verin's stocky gray-haired Tomas sat next to a grizzled fellow with only a fringe of white hair remaining. "Darner, he wanted to try his Healing on her, but Daigian refused. She may never have had a Warder before, but she knows that the grieving over a dead Warder is part of remembering him. I am surprised that Corele would consider allowing it."

wɪð ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ðə tæɹɑbənɝ sɪstɝ ɹɪtɝn tə stʌɾiɪŋ dʒɑhɹ. ʌðɝ sɪstɝz' wɔɹɾɝz dɪd nɑt ɹɪli ɪntʃɹəs hɝ, ət lis nɑt laɪk əɹ oʊn. "æʃəmən, ðeɪ ɡɹiv əz wɔɹɾɝz du. aɪ θɔt pɝhæps dʒɑhɹ ən dɑɹnɝ mɪɹli fɑloʊd ðə lɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝz, bʌt dʒɑhɹ, hi sɛz ɪts ðɛɹ weɪ, tu. aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹud, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ wɑtʃt əm dʒɹɪŋk ɪn mɛmɹi ʌv deɪdʒiənz jʌŋ ɛbən. ðeɪ nɛvɝ mɛnʃən ɪz neɪm, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ə fʊl waɪnkʌp sɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. bæsɑn ən nɛθən, ðeɪ noʊ ðeɪ kən daɪ ɑn ɛni deɪ, ən ðeɪ æksɛp ðæt. dʒɑhɹ ɪkspɛks tə daɪ; ɛvɹi deɪ hi ɪkspɛks ɪt. tə hɪm, ɛvɹi aʊɝ ɪz moʊst əʃʊɹədli hɪz læst." kædzueɪn bɛɹli ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm ɡlænsɪŋ ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. mɛɹaɪs dɪd nɑɾ ɔfən ɡoʊ ɑn ət sətʃ lɛŋθ. ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz feɪs wɑz smuð, hɝ mænɝ ənɹʌfəld, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ hæɾ əpsɛt hɝ. "aɪ noʊ jə pɹæktəs lɪŋkɪŋ wɪð hɪm," ʃi sɛd dɛləkətli, piɹɪŋ daʊn ɪndə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. dɛləkəsi wɑz ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɪn tɔkɪŋ tə ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ əbaʊɾ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹizən ʃi stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "hæv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd jɛt wɛðɝ ði ælθɹ bɔɪ səksiɾəd ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ? dɪɾ i ɹɪli mænədʒ tə klɛnz ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs?" kɔɹəl pɹæktəs lɪŋkɪŋ wɪð deɪmɝ, tu, bʌt ðə jɛloʊ wɑz soʊ foʊkəst ɑn əɹ fjuɾəl ɛfɝts tə ɹizən aʊt haʊ tə də wɪð seɪaɪdɑɹ wʌɾ i dɪd wɪð seɪɾɪn ðət ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv noʊɾəst ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. ə pɪɾi ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɑt kʌm tə ðə ʃɔl fɪfti jɪɹz leɪɾɝ ðən ʃi hæd, əɹ ʃi wʊɾə bɑndəd wʌn ə ðə mɛn hɝsɛlf ən hæd noʊ nid tə æsk. bʌt fɪfti jɪɹz wʊɾə mɛn ðət nɔɹlə daɪɾ ɪn əɹ lɪɾəl haʊs ɪn ðə blæk hɪlz bɪfɔɹ kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn ɛvɝ wɛn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðət wʊɾə ɔltɝɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə hɪstɝi. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ənlaɪkli ðət ʃi wəd bi ɪn ɛniθɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ əɹ pɹɛzən sɝkəmstænsəz. soʊ ʃi æskt, dɛləkətli, ən weɪɾəd.

With a shake of her head, the Taraboner sister returned to studying Jahar. Other sisters' Warders did not really interest her, at least not like her own. "Asha'man, they grieve as Warders do. I thought perhaps Jahar and Darner merely followed the lead of the others, but Jahar, he says it is their way, too. I did not intrude, of course, but I watched them drink in memory of Daigian's young Eben. They never mentioned his name, but they had a full winecup sitting for him. Bassane and Nethan, they know they can die on any day, and they accept that. Jahar expects to die; every day he expects it. To him, every hour is most assuredly his last." Cadsuane barely refrained from glancing at the other woman. Merise did not often go on at such length. The other woman's face was smooth, her manner unruffled, but something had upset her. "I know you practice linking with him," she said delicately, peering down into the courtyard. Delicacy was required in talking to another sister about her Warder. That was part of the reason she stared into the courtyard, frowning. "Have you decided yet whether the al'Thor boy succeeded at Shadar Logoth? Did he really manage to cleanse the male half of the Source?" Corele practiced linking with Damer, too, but the Yellow was so focused on her futile efforts to reason out how to do with saidar what he did with saidin that she would not have noticed the Dark One's taint sliding down her throat. A pity she herself had not come to the shawl fifty years later than she had, or she would have bonded one of the men herself and had no need to ask. But fifty years would have meant that Norla died in her little house in the Black Hills before Cadsuane Melaidhrin ever went to the White Tower. That would have altered a great deal of history. For one thing, it would have been unlikely that she would be in anything approaching her present circumstances. So she asked, delicately, and waited.

mɛɹaɪs wɑz kwaɪət, ən stɪl, fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ən ðən ʃi saɪd. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ, kædzueɪn.

Merise was quiet, and still, for a long moment, and then she sighed. "I do not know, Cadsuane.

seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪz ə kɑm oʊʃən ðət wɪl teɪk jə wɛɹɛvɝ jə wɑn soʊ lɔŋ əz jə noʊ ðə kɝəns ən lɛɾ əm kæɹi ju. seɪɾɪn. . . . ən ævəlæntʃ ə bɝnɪŋ stoʊn. kəlæpsɪŋ maʊntənz ʌv aɪs. ɪt filz klinɝ ðən wən aɪ fɝs lɪŋkt wɪð dʒɑhɹ, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd haɪɾ ɪn ðət keɪɑs. ɛniθɪŋ." kædzueɪn nɑɾəd.

Saidar is a calm ocean that will take you wherever you want so long as you know the currents and let them carry you. Saidin. . . . An avalanche of burning stone. Collapsing mountains of ice. It feels cleaner than when I first linked with Jahar, but anything could hide in that chaos. Anything." Cadsuane nodded.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛni ʌðɝ ænsɝ. waɪ ʃəd ʃi faɪn ɛni sɝɾənti əbaʊt wʌn ə ðə tu moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt kwɛstʃənz ɪn ðə wɝld wən ʃi kəd faɪnd nʌn ɑn soʊ mɛni sɪmpəlɝ mæɾɝz? ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd, lænz wʊɾən bleɪd stɑpt, nɑt wɪð ə kɹæk ðɪs taɪm, dʒʌs tʌtʃɪŋ dʒɑhɹz θɹoʊt, ən ðə bɪɡɝ mæn floʊd bæk tə hɪz weɪɾɪŋ stæns. nɛθən stʊɾ əɡɛn, ən əɡɛn dʒɑhɹ weɪvd ɪm bæk, æŋɡɹəli ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən sɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. mɛɹaɪsəz θɝd, bæsɑn, ə ʃɔɹt waɪd fɛloʊ nɪɹli əz sʌn-dɑɹk əz dʒɑhɹ fəɹ ɔl i wɑz kɛɹhinɪn, læft ən meɪɾ ə ɹud kɑmɛn əbaʊɾ oʊvɝ-æmbɪʃəs mɛn tʃɹɪpɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn bleɪdz. toʊmɑs ən dɑɹnɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz ən ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz; mɛn ə ðəɾ eɪdʒ juʒəwəli hæd ɡɪvən ʌp tɔntɪŋ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðə klæk ʌv wʊɾ ɑn wʊd bɪɡæn wʌns mɔɹ. ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli ɑɾiəns fəɹ læn ən dʒɑhɹ ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. ðə slɪm ɡɝl wɪð əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ ɪn ə lɔŋ bɹeɪd, wɑtʃɪŋ æŋkʃəsli fɹəm ə ɹɛd bɛntʃ, wɑz ðə foʊkəs ə kædzueɪnz fɹaʊn. ðə tʃaɪld wəd nid tə flæʃ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ʌndɝ pipəlz noʊzɪz tə bi teɪkən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪtʃ ʃi wɑz, ɪf dʒʌs tɛknɪkəli. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli kəz nɪneɪivz feɪs wɑz ə ɡɝlz feɪs; bɛldaɪn stɪl simd əz jʌŋ. nɪneɪiv baʊnst ɑn ðə bɛntʃ, ɔlweɪz ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə lipɪŋ ʌp. əkeɪʒənəli hɝ maʊθ muvd əz ɪf ʃi wɝ saɪlənli ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, ən səmtaɪmz əɹ hænz twɪstəɾ əz ðoʊ dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ haʊ læn ʃʊɾə muvd ɪz sɔɹd. ə fɹɪvələs ɡɝl, fʊl ə pæʃənz, hu oʊnli ɹɛɹli dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd ðət ʃi hæɾ ə bɹeɪn. mɪn wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə hæv θɹoʊn əɹ hɑɹɾ ən hɛd boʊθ daʊn ðə wɛl oʊvɝ ə mæn. baɪ ðə kʌstəmz ə dɛd mɔlkiɝ, ðə ɹɛd dɑt peɪntəɾ ɑn nɪneɪivz fɔɹhɛɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ tə læn, ðoʊ jɛloʊz sɛldəm mɛɹid ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz. vɛɹi fju sɪstɝz dɪd, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ən ə kɔɹs, læn wɑz nɑt nɪneɪivz wɔɹɾɝ, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ i ən ðə ɡɝl pɹitɛndəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz. hu hi dɪd bɪlɔŋ tə wɑz ə mæɾɝ ðeɪ ɪveɪɾɪd laɪk θivz slɪpɪŋ θɹu ðə naɪt. mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, mɔɹ dɪstɝbɪŋ, wɑz ðə dʒuəlɹi nɪneɪiv wɔɹ, ə lɔŋ ɡoʊl nɛkləs ən slɪm ɡoʊl bɛlt, wɪð mætʃɪŋ bɹeɪslɪts ən fɪŋɡɝ ɹɪŋz, ðə ɡɔɾi ɹɛɾ ən ɡɹin ən blu dʒɛmz ðət stʌɾɪd əm klæʃɪŋ wɪð əɹ jɛloʊ-slæʃt dʒɹɛs. ən ʃi wɔɹ ðət pəkjuljɝ pis əz wɛl, ɑn əɹ lɛf hænd, ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋz ətætʃt tə ə ɡoʊldən bɹeɪslət baɪ flæt tʃeɪnz. ðət wɑz ən æŋɡɹil, mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən kædzueɪnz ʃɹaɪk hɛɹ ɔɹnəmənt. ði ʌðɝz wɝ mʌtʃ laɪk əɹ oʊn dɛkɝeɪʃənz, tu, tɛɹæŋɡɹil ən pleɪnli meɪɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm, dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt faɪn mɛni hænz tɝn əɡɛns hɝ, moʊst ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz ə mɛn u kəd tʃænəl. stʃɹeɪnʒ tə θɪŋk ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu. ɪt wəd bi laɪk miɾɪŋ ə mæn kɔl kædzueɪn.

She was not sure she had expected any other answer. Why should she find any certainty about one of the two most important questions in the world when she could find none on so many simpler matters? In the courtyard, Lan's wooden blade stopped, not with a crack this time, just touching Jahar's throat, and the bigger man flowed back to his waiting stance. Nethan stood again, and again Jahar waved him back, angrily raising his sword and setting himself. Merise's third, Bassane, a short wide fellow nearly as sun-dark as Jahar for all he was Cairhienin, laughed and made a rude comment about over-ambitious men tripping on their own blades. Tomas and Darner exchanged glances and shook their heads; men of that age usually had given up taunting long ago. The clack of wood on wood began once more. The other four Warders were not the only audience for Lan and Jahar in the courtyard. The slim girl with her dark hair in a long braid, watching anxiously from a red bench, was the focus of Cadsuane's frown. The child would need to flash her Great Serpent ring under people's noses to be taken for Aes Sedai, which she was, if just technically. It was not only because Nynaeve's face was a girl's face; Beldeine still seemed as young. Nynaeve bounced on the bench, always on the point of leaping up. Occasionally her mouth moved as if she were silently shouting encouragement, and sometimes her hands twisted as though demonstrating how Lan should have moved his sword. A frivolous girl, full of passions, who only rarely demonstrated that she had a brain. Min was not the only one to have thrown her heart and head both down the well over a man. By the customs of dead Malkier, the red dot painted on Nynaeve's forehead indicated her marriage to Lan, though Yellows seldom married their Warders. Very few sisters did, for that matter. And of course, Lan was not Nynaeve's Warder, however much he and the girl pretended otherwise. Who he did belong to was a matter they evaded like thieves slipping through the night. More interesting, more disturbing, was the jewelry Nynaeve wore, a long gold necklace and slim gold belt, with matching bracelets and finger rings, the gaudy red and green and blue gems that studded them clashing with her yellow-slashed dress. And she wore that peculiar piece as well, on her left hand, golden rings attached to a golden bracelet by flat chains. That was an angreal, much stronger than Cadsuane's shrike hair ornament. The others were much like her own decorations, too, ter'angreal and plainly made at the same time, during the Breaking of the World, when an Aes Sedai might find many hands turned against her, most especially those of men who could channel. Strange to think that they had been called Aes Sedai, too. It would be like meeting a man called Cadsuane.

ðə kwɛstʃən - hɝ mɔɹnɪŋ sim fɪld wɪð kwɛstʃənz, ən ðə sʌn nɑt hæfweɪ tə nun jɛt -  ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz, dɪd ðə ɡɝl wɛɹ əɹ dʒuəlɹi kəz ə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ, əɹ ði æʃəmən? əɹ kəz ə kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn? nɪneɪiv hæd dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd əɹ lɔɪəlti tə ə jʌŋ mæn fɹəm əɹ oʊn vɪlədʒ, ən ʃi hæd ʃoʊn əɹ wɛɹinɪs ə hɪm əz wɛl. ʃi dɪɾ əv ə bɹeɪn, wən ʃi tʃoʊz tə juz ɪt. əntɪl ðət kwɛstʃən wɑz ænsɝd, haʊɛvɝ, tʃɹʌstɪŋ ðə ɡɝl tu fɑɹ wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, lɪɾəl ðiz deɪz dɪd nɑt sim deɪnʒɝəs.

The question - her morning seemed filled with questions, and the sun not halfway to noon yet -  the question was, did the girl wear her jewelry because of the al'Thor boy, or the Asha'man? Or because of Cadsuane Melaidhrin? Nynaeve had demonstrated her loyalty to a young man from her own village, and she had shown her wariness of him as well. She did have a brain, when she chose to use it. Until that question was answered, however, trusting the girl too far was dangerous. The trouble was, little these days did not seem dangerous.

"dʒɑhɹ ɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ," mɛɹaɪs sɛɾ əbɹʌpli.

"Jahar is growing stronger," Merise said abruptly.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, kædzueɪn fɹaʊn ət ði ʌðɝ ɡɹin. stʃɹɔŋɝ? ðə jʌŋ mænz ʃɝt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə klɪŋ dæmpli tə hɪz bæk, waɪl læn əpɪɹd nɑt tə hæv bɹoʊkən ɪz fɝst swɛt. ðən ʃi ʌndɝstʊd. mɛɹaɪs mɛn ɪn ðə paʊɝ. kædzueɪn oʊnli ɹeɪzd ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ, ðoʊ. ʃi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ðə læs taɪm ʃi hæd lɛt ʃɑk ɹitʃ əɹ feɪs. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ɪn ðə blæk hɪlz, wən ʃi bɪɡæn ɝnɪŋ ði ɔɹnəməns ʃi naʊ wɔɹ.

For an instant, Cadsuane frowned at the other Green. Stronger? The young man's shirt was beginning to cling damply to his back, while Lan appeared not to have broken his first sweat. Then she understood. Merise meant in the Power. Cadsuane only raised a questioning eyebrow, though. She could not recall the last time she had let shock reach her face. It might have been all those years ago, in the Black Hills, when she began earning the ornaments she now wore.

"æt fɝst, aɪ θɔt ðə weɪ ðiz æʃəmən tʃɹeɪn, ðə fɔɹsɪŋ, hæd pʊʃt ɪm tə hɪz fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ ɔlɹɛɾi," mɛɹaɪs sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət ðə tu mɛn wɝkɪŋ ðɛɹ pɹæktəs bleɪdz. noʊ; ɪt wɑz ət dʒɑhɹ ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ. dʒʌst ə feɪn kɹɪŋkəl ə hɝ aɪz, bʌt ʃi ɹɪzɝvd əɹ fɹaʊnz fəɹ ðoʊz u kəd si ən noʊ hɝ dɪsplɛʒɝ. "æt ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ mʌs bi ɪmædʒənɪŋ ɪt. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz əɡoʊ, aɪ wɑz hæf kənvɪnst aɪ wɑz mɪsteɪkən. naʊ, aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪm kɝɛkt. ɪf mɛn ɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ baɪ fɪts ən stɑɹts, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ seɪɪŋ haʊ stʃɹɔŋ hɪl bɪkʌm."

"At first, I thought the way these Asha'man train, the forcing, had pushed him to his full strength already," Merise said, frowning down at the two men working their practice blades. No; it was at Jahar she was frowning. Just a faint crinkle of her eyes, but she reserved her frowns for those who could see and know her displeasure. "At Shadar Logoth, I thought I must be imagining it. Three or four days ago, I was half convinced I was mistaken. Now, I am sure I am correct. If men gain strength by fits and starts, there is no saying how strong he will become."

ʃi dɪd nɑt vɔɪs əɹ ɑbviəs wɝi, ʌv kɔɹs: ðəɾ i maɪt ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʃi. seɪɪŋ sətʃ ə θɪŋ wʊɾə bɪn ənθɪŋkəbəl ɑn mɛni dɪfɹən lɛvəlz, ən waɪl mɛɹaɪs hæd bɪkʌm sʌmwʌɾ əkʌstəm tə duɪŋ ði ənθɪŋkəbəl - moʊst sɪstɝz wəd feɪn ət ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə ʌv bɑndɪŋ ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl - ʃi wɑz nɛvɝ kʌmftəɹbəl ɡɪvɪŋ əm vɔɪs. kædzueɪn wɑz, jɛt ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs nutʃɹəl. laɪt, bʌt ʃi heɪɾəd biɪŋ dɛləkət. heɪɾəd ðə nəsɛsəɾi, ɛniweɪ.

She did not voice her obvious worry, of course: that he might grow stronger than she. Saying such a thing would have been unthinkable on many different levels, and while Merise had become somewhat accustomed to doing the unthinkable - most sisters would faint at the very idea of bonding a man who could channel - she was never comfortable giving them voice. Cadsuane was, yet she kept her voice neutral. Light, but she hated being delicate. Hated the necessity, anyway.

"hi simz kɑntɛnt, mɛɹaɪs." mɛɹaɪsəz wɔɹɾɝz ɔlweɪz sim kɑntɛnt; ʃi hændəld əm wɛl.

"He seems content, Merise." Merise's Warders always seemed content; she handled them well.

"hi ɪz ɪn ə fjʊɹi ʌv. . . . " ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tʌtʃt ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛɾ əz ðoʊ fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə bʌndəl ə sɛnseɪʃənz ʃi fɛl θɹu ðə bɑnd. ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ʌpsɛt! "nɑt ɹeɪdʒ. fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən." ɹitʃɪŋ ɪndə hɝ ɡɹin wɝkt-lɛðɝ bɛl paʊtʃ, ʃi tʊk aʊɾ ə smɔl ɪnæməl pɪn, ə sɪnwəs fɪɡjɝ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld, laɪk ə sneɪk wɪð lɛɡz ən ə laɪənz meɪn. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ði ælθɹ læd ɡɑt ðɪs, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv ɪt tə dʒɑhɹ. əpɛɹənli, fəɹ æʃəmən, ɪts əkɪn tə əteɪnɪŋ ðə ʃɔl. aɪ hæd tə teɪk ɪɾ əweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs; dʒɑhɹ, hiz stɪl ət ðə steɪdʒ wɛɹ hiz tə lɝn tə æksɛpt oʊnli wʌɾ aɪ seɪ hi kæn. bʌt hiz soʊ ædʒəteɪɾəd oʊvɝ ðə θɪŋ. . . . ʃəɾ aɪ ɡɪv ɪt bæk tə hɪm? ɪn ə weɪ, ɪt wəd kʌm fɹəm maɪ hænd, ðɛn." kædzueɪnz aɪbɹaʊz bɪɡæn tə klaɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kəntʃɹoʊl ðɛm. mɛɹaɪs wɑz æskɪŋ ædvaɪs əbaʊt wʌn ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝz? ʌv kɔɹs, kædzueɪn hæd sədʒɛstəd ʃi saʊn ðə mæn aʊɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, bʌt ðɪs dɪɡɹi ʌv ɪntəməsi wɑz. . . . ənθɪŋkəbəl? fɔ! "aɪm ʃʊɹ wʌtɛvɝ jə dɪsaɪd wɪl bi kɝɛkt." wɪð wʌn læst ɡlæns ət nɪneɪiv, ʃi lɛf ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ði ɪnæməl pɪn wɪð əɹ θʌm ən fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ɪndə ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd. læn hæd dʒʌs dɪfiɾəd dʒɑhɹ wʌns mɔɹ, bʌt ðə jʌŋ mæn wɑz skwɛɹɪŋ ʌp əɡɛn, dɪmændɪŋ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ mætʃ. wʌtɛvɝ mɛɹaɪs dɪsaɪɾɪd, ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɝnd wʌn θɪŋ ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk. ðə baʊndɝiz bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn əz klɪɹ əz ðə kənɛkʃənz; ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmændəd, ən wɔɹɾɝz oʊbeɪd. bʌɾ ɪf mɛɹaɪs, ʌv ɔl pipəl, wɑz dɪðɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ə kɑlɝ pɪn - mɛɹaɪs, hu mænədʒd əɹ wɔɹɾɝz wɪð ə fɝm hænd - ðən nu baʊndɝiz wəɾ əv tə bi wɝkt aʊt, ət list wɪð wɔɹɾɝz u kəd tʃænəl. ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðət bɑndɪŋ əm wəd stɑp naʊ; bɛldaɪn wɑz ɛvəɾəns fəɹ ðæt. pipəl nɛvɝ ɹɪli tʃeɪnʒd, jɛt ðə wɝl dɪd, wɪð dɪstɝbɪŋ ɹɛɡjəlɛɹəɾi. jə dʒʌs hæd tə lɪv wɪð ɪt, əɹ ət lis lɪv θɹu ɪt. naʊ ən ðɛn, wɪð lʌk, jə kəɾ əfɛk ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə tʃeɪnʒəz, bʌɾ ivən ɪf jə stɑpt wʌn, jə oʊnli sɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɪn moʊʃən. əz ɪkspɛktəd, ʃi dɪd nɑt faɪn ðə dɔɹ tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪz ɹumz ənɡɑɹɾɪd. əliviə wɑz ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs, siɾəd ɑn ə bɛntʃ tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹ wɪð əɹ hænz foʊldəd peɪʃənli ɪn əɹ læp. ðə peɪl-hɛɹd sintʃæn wʊmən hæɾ əpɔɪntəd hɝsɛlf ðə bɔɪz pɹətɛktɝ, ʌv sɔɹts. əliviə kɹɛɾətəd ɪm wɪð fɹiɪŋ əɹ fɹəm ə deɪmeɪnz kɑlɝ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ðæt. mɪn dɪslaɪk hɝ, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə juʒəwəl sɔɹɾ ə dʒɛləsi. əliviə hɑɹdli sim tə noʊ wʌt mɛn ən wɪmən dɪd təɡɛðɝ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə kənɛkʃən bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə bɔɪ, ə kənɛkʃən ɹɪvild ɪn ɡlænsɪz ðət kæɹid dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɑn əɹ saɪɾ ən ɑn hɪz, hoʊp, hɑɹɾ əz ðət wɑz tə bɪliv. əntɪl kædzueɪn nu wʌt ðət wɑz ɔl əbaʊt, ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə də nʌθɪŋ tə sɛpɝeɪt ðɛm. əliviəz ʃɑɹp blu aɪz ɹəɡɑɹɾəd kædzueɪn wɪð ə ɹɪspɛkfəl wɛɹinɪs, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt si ən ɛnəmi. əliviə hæɾ ə ʃɔɹt weɪ wɪð ðoʊz ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ði ælθɹ bɔɪz ɛnəmiz. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɑn ɡɑɹd wɑz mʌtʃ ʌv ə saɪz wɪð əliviə, bʌt ðə tu kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ dɪfɹənt, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ɛlzəz aɪz wɝ bɹaʊn ən ʃi hæd ðə smuð, eɪdʒləs lʊk ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɛɹ əliviə hæd faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz ən θɹɛdz ʌv waɪɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɾən ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. ɛlzə lɛp tə hɝ fiɾ əz sun əz ʃi sɔ kædzueɪn, dʒɹɔɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ ən ɹæpɪŋ hɝsɛlf taɪɾ ɪn əɹ ʃɔl. "hi ɪz nɑɾ əloʊn," ʃi sɛd, fɹɔst ɹaɪmɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs.

"He is in a fury of. . . . " The other woman touched the side of her head as though fingering the bundle of sensations she felt through the bond. She really was upset! "Not rage. Frustration." Reaching into her green worked-leather belt pouch, she took out a small enameled pin, a sinuous figure in red and gold, like a snake with legs and a lion's mane. "I do not know where the al'Thor lad got this, but he gave it to Jahar. Apparently, for Asha'man, it is akin to attaining the shawl. I had to take it away, of course; Jahar, he is still at the stage where he has to learn to accept only what I say he can. But he is so agitated over the thing. . . . Should I give it back to him? In a way, it would come from my hand, then." Cadsuane's eyebrows began to climb before she could control them. Merise was asking advice about one of her Warders? Of course, Cadsuane had suggested she sound the man out in the first place, but this degree of intimacy was. . . . Unthinkable? Phaw! "I'm sure whatever you decide will be correct." With one last glance at Nynaeve, she left the taller woman stroking the enameled pin with her thumb and frowning down into the courtyard. Lan had just defeated Jahar once more, but the young man was squaring up again, demanding yet another match. Whatever Merise decided, she had already learned one thing she did not like. The boundaries between Aes Sedai and Warders had always been as clear as the connections; Aes Sedai commanded, and Warders obeyed. But if Merise, of all people, was dithering over a collar pin - Merise, who managed her Warders with a firm hand - then new boundaries would have to be worked out, at least with Warders who could channel. It seemed unlikely that bonding them would stop now; Beldeine was evidence for that. People never really changed, yet the world did, with disturbing regularity. You just had to live with it, or at least live through it. Now and then, with luck, you could affect the direction of the changes, but even if you stopped one, you only set another in motion. As expected, she did not find the door to the al'Thor boy's rooms unguarded. Alivia was there, of course, seated on a bench to one side of the door with her hands folded patiently in her lap. The pale-haired Seanchan woman had appointed herself the boy's protector, of sorts. Alivia credited him with freeing her from a damane's collar, but there was more to it than that. Min disliked her, for one thing, and it was not the usual sort of jealousy. Alivia hardly seemed to know what men and women did together. But there was a connection between her and the boy, a connection revealed in glances that carried determination on her side and on his, hope, hard as that was to believe. Until Cadsuane knew what that was all about, she intended to do nothing to separate them. Alivia's sharp blue eyes regarded Cadsuane with a respectful wariness, but she did not see an enemy. Alivia had a short way with those she considered the al'Thor boy's enemies. The other woman on guard was much of a size with Alivia, but the two could not have been more different, and not just because Elza's eyes were brown and she had the smooth, ageless look of Aes Sedai, where Alivia had fine lines at the corners of her eyes and threads of white almost hidden in her hair. Elza leaped to her feet as soon as she saw Cadsuane, drawing herself up in front of the door and wrapping herself tight in her shawl. "He is not alone," she said, frost riming her voice.

"du jə min tə stæn ɪn maɪ weɪ?" kædzueɪn æskt, dʒʌst əz koʊldli. ði ændɔɝən ɡɹin ʃʊɾə muvd əsaɪd. ɛlzə stʊd fɑɹ ɪnʌf bɪloʊ hɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ðət ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, mʌtʃ lɛs weɪɾəd, fəɹ ə kəmænd, bʌt ðə wʊmən plæntəɾ əɹ fit, ən əɹ ɡeɪz æktʃəli  ɡɹu hiɾəd.

"Do you mean to stand in my way?" Cadsuane asked, just as coldly. The Andoran Green should have moved aside. Elza stood far enough below her in the Power that she should not have hesitated, much less waited, for a command, but the woman planted her feet, and her gaze actually grew heated.

ɪt wɑz ə kwɑndɝi. faɪv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə mænɝ haʊs swɔɹn fiəlti tə ðə bɔɪ, ən ðoʊz u hæd bɪn lɔɪəl tə ɪleɪɾə ɔl stɛɹɾ ət kædzueɪn əz ɪf səspɪʃəs ə hɝ ɪntɛntʃənz təwɔɹd hɪm. wɪtʃ ɹeɪz ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv waɪ vɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt, ʌv kɔɹs. bʌɾ oʊnli ɛlzə tʃɹaɪd tə kip əɹ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. ðə wʊmənz æɾətud ɹikt ə dʒɛləsi, wɪtʃ meɪd noʊ sɛns. ʃi kəd nɑt pɑsəbli bɪliv hɝsɛlf bɛɾɝ suɾəd tə ædvaɪz hɪm, ən ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ðəɾ ɛlzə dɪzaɪɝd ðə bɔɪ, əz ə mæn əɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ, mɪn wʊɾə bɪn snɑɹlɪŋ. ðə ɡɝl hæd faɪnli hoʊn ɪnstɪŋks, ðɛɹ. kædzueɪn wəɾ əv ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ, hæd ʃi bɪn ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv wʊmən tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ.

It was a quandary. Five other sisters in the manor house sworn fealty to the boy, and those who had been loyal to Elaida all stared at Cadsuane as if suspicious of her intentions toward him. Which raised the question of why Verin did not, of course. But only Elza tried to keep her away from him. The woman's attitude reeked of jealousy, which made no sense. She could not possibly believe herself better suited to advise him, and if there had been any suggestion that Elza desired the boy, as a man or a Warder, Min would have been snarling. The girl had finely honed instincts, there. Cadsuane would have ground her teeth, had she been the sort of woman to grind her teeth.

ət ðə pɔɪnt wən ʃi θɔt ʃi wəɾ əv tə ɔɹɾɝ ɛlzə tə stɛp əsaɪd, əliviə lin fɔɹwɝd.

At the point when she thought she would have to order Elza to step aside, Alivia leaned forward.

"hi dɪd sɛn fəɹ hɝ, ɛlzə," ʃi dʒɹɔld. "hil bi əpsɛɾ ɪf wi kip əɹ aʊt. əpsɛt wɪð ʌs, nɑt hɝ. lɛɾ əɹ ɪn."

"He did send for her, Elza," she drawled. "He'll be upset if we keep her out. Upset with us, not her. Let her in."

ɛlzə ɡlænst ət ðə sintʃæn wʊmən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, ən əɹ lɪp kɝld ɪn kəntɛmpt.

Elza glanced at the Seanchan woman from the corner of her eye, and her lip curled in contempt.

əliviə stʊd fɑɹ əbʌv əɹ ɪn ðə paʊɝ - əliviə stʊd wɛl əbʌv kædzueɪn, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ - bʌt ʃi wɑz ə waɪldɝ, ən ə laɪɝ ɪn ɛlzəz vju. ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən hɑɹdli sim tə æksɛp ðəɾ əliviə hæd bɪn deɪmeɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ stɔɹi. stɪl, ɛlzə dɑɹɾɪd ə lʊk ət kædzueɪn, ðən ət ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ, ən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl. pleɪnli, ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðə bɔɪ ʌpsɛt. nɑt wɪð hɝ.

Alivia stood far above her in the Power - Alivia stood well above Cadsuane, for that matter - but she was a wilder, and a liar in Elza's view. The dark-haired woman hardly seemed to accept that Alivia had been damane, much less the rest of her story. Still, Elza darted a look at Cadsuane, then at the door behind her, and shifted her shawl. Plainly, she did not want the boy upset. Not with her.

"aɪl si wɛðɝ hiz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ju," ʃi sɛd, vɛɹi nɪɹ tə sʌlən. "kip əɹ hɪɹ," ʃi æɾəd tə əliviə, mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli, bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə nɑk laɪtli ət ðə dɔɹ. ə meɪl vɔɪs kɔl fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ən ʃi oʊpən ðə dɔɹ dʒʌst waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə slɪp ɪn, pʊlɪŋ ɪt ʃʌt bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"I'll see whether he's ready for you," she said, very near to sullen. "Keep her here," she added to Alivia, more sharply, before turning to knock lightly at the door. A male voice called from the other side, and she opened the door just wide enough to slip in, pulling it shut behind her.

"jul əv tə fɝɡɪv hɝ," əliviə sɛɾ ɪn ðəɾ ɪɹɪteɪɾɪŋli sloʊ, sɑf sintʃæn æksɛnt. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪts dʒʌs ðət ʃi teɪks əɹ oʊθ vɛɹi sɪɹiəsli. ʃi ɪzən juz tə sɝvɪŋ ɛniwʌn." "ɛɛs sədaɪ kip ðɛɹ wɝd," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. ðə wʊmən meɪɾ əɹ fil əz ɪf əɹ oʊn weɪ ʌv tɔkɪŋ wɝ əz kwɪk ən kɹɪsp əz ə kɛɹhinɪnz! "wi mʌst."

"You'll have to forgive her," Alivia said in that irritatingly slow, soft Seanchan accent. "I think it's just that she takes her oath very seriously. She isn't used to serving anyone." "Aes Sedai keep their word," Cadsuane replied dryly. The woman made her feel as if her own way of talking were as quick and crisp as a Cairhienin's! "We must."

"aɪ θɪŋk jə du. dʒʌst soʊ jə noʊ, aɪ kip maɪ wɝd, tu. aɪ oʊ hɪm ɛniθɪŋ i wɑns ə mi." ə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ kɑmɛnt, ən ən oʊpənɪŋ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ɪt, ɛlzə keɪm aʊt. bɪhaɪn əɹ keɪm ælɡɝɪn, waɪt bɪɹd tʃɹɪm tə ə nit pɔɪnt. hi ɔfɝd kædzueɪn ə baʊ, wɪð ə smaɪl ðət dipən ðə ɹɪŋkəlz ə hɪz feɪs. hɪz pleɪn koʊɾ ə dɑɹk wʊl, meɪɾ ɪn ɪz jʌŋɡɝ deɪz, hʌŋ lusli ɑn ɪm naʊ, ən ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd pɹəvaɪɾəd ə θɪn kʌvɝɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃæns tə faɪn aʊt waɪ hi hæd bɪn vɪzəɾɪŋ ði ælθɹ bɔɪ. "hi wɪl si jə naʊ," ɛlzə sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

"I think you do. Just so you know, I keep my word, too. I owe him anything he wants of me." A fascinating comment, and an opening, but before she could take advantage of it, Elza came out. Behind her came Algarin, white beard trimmed to a neat point. He offered Cadsuane a bow, with a smile that deepened the wrinkles of his face. His plain coat of dark wool, made in his younger days, hung loosely on him now, and the hair on his head provided a thin covering. There was no chance to find out why he had been visiting the al'Thor boy. "He will see you now," Elza said sharply.

kædzueɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli dɪd ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ. əliviə wəɾ əv tə weɪt. ən ælɡɝɪn.

Cadsuane very nearly did grind her teeth. Alivia would have to wait. And Algarin.

ðə bɔɪ wɑz ɑn ɪz fit wən kædzueɪn ɛntɝd, ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl ən bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝɾ əz læn ɪn ə blæk koʊt wɝkt wɪð ɡoʊld ɑn ðə slivz ən ðə haɪ kɑlɝ. ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ laɪk ən æʃəmənz koʊt wɪð ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi æɾəd tə sut hɝ, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. hi meɪɾ ə kɝɾiəs baʊ, ʌʃɝɪŋ əɹ tə ə tʃɛɹ wɪð ə tæsɛl kʊʃən ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən æskɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi wəd laɪk waɪn. ðəɾ ɪn ðə pɪtʃɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə saɪd teɪbəl wɪð tu waɪnkʌps hæd ɡɔn koʊld, bʌɾ i kəd sɛn fəɹ mɔɹ. ʃi hæd wɝk hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə fɔɹs ɪm ɪndə səvɪləɾi; hi kəd wɛɹ ɛni koʊɾ i wɑntəd. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz i hæd tə bi ɡaɪɾəd ɪn. əɹ pɹɑɾɪd, əɹ pʊld əz nid bi. ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə weɪs taɪm əɹ tɔk ɑn ɪz kloʊðɪŋ.

The boy was on his feet when Cadsuane entered, almost as tall and broad-shouldered as Lan in a black coat worked with gold on the sleeves and the high collar. It was too much like an Asha'man's coat with embroidery added to suit her, but she said nothing. He made a courteous bow, ushering her to a chair with a tasseled cushion in front of the fireplace and asking whether she would like wine. That in the pitcher sitting on a side table with two winecups had gone cold, but he could send for more. She had worked hard enough to force him into civility; he could wear any coat he wanted. There were more important matters he had to be guided in. Or prodded, or pulled as need be. She was not going to waste time or talk on his clothing.

ɪnklaɪnɪŋ əɹ hɛd pəlaɪtli, ʃi dɪklaɪn ðə waɪn. ə waɪnkʌp ɔfɝd mɛni ɑpɝtunəɾiz - tə sɪp wən jə niɾəd ə moʊməns θɔt; tə pɪɹ ɪndə wən jə wɪʃt tə haɪd jəɹ aɪz - jɛt ðɪs jʌŋ mæn niɾəd wɑtʃɪŋ ɛvɹi moʊmənt. hɪz feɪs ɡeɪv əweɪ ɔlmoʊst əz lɪɾəl əz ə sɪstɝz. wɪð ðət dɑɹk ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ ən ðoʊz blu-ɡɹeɪ aɪz, hi cʊɾə pæs fəɹ il, bʌt fju il hæɾ aɪz ðət koʊld.

Inclining her head politely, she declined the wine. A winecup offered many opportunities - to sip when you needed a moment's thought; to peer into when you wished to hide your eyes - yet this young man needed watching every moment. His face gave away almost as little as a sister's. With that dark reddish hair and those blue-gray eyes, he could have passed for Aiel, but few Aiel had eyes that cold.

ðeɪ meɪd ðə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ ʃi hæd bɪn stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɝliɝ sim wɔɹm. koʊldɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. hɑɹɾɝ, tu, ənfɔɹtʃənətli. ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ lʊkt . . . wɪɹi. "ælɡɝɪn hæɾ ə bɹʌðɝ u kəd tʃænəl," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə feɪsɪŋ tʃɛɹ. hæfweɪ ɪndə ðə tɝn, hi stæɡɝd. hi kɑt hɪmsɛlf ɑn ən ɑɹm ə ðə tʃɛɹ wɪð ə bɑɹk læf, pɹitɛndɪŋ i hæd tʃɹɪpt oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn buts, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ tʃɹɪpɪŋ. ən i hæd nɑt siz seɪɾɪn - ʃi hæd sin ɪm stæɡɝ, duɪŋ ðət - əɹ əɹ ɔɹnəməns wʊɾə wɔɹn hɝ. kɔɹəl sɛɾ i oʊnli niɾəd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ slip tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. laɪt, ʃi niɾəd tə kip ðə bɔɪ əlaɪv, əɹ ɪt hæɾ ɔl bɪn fəɹ nʌθɪŋ!

They made the morning sky she had been staring at earlier seem warm. Colder than they had been before Shadar Logoth. Harder, too, unfortunately. They also looked . . . weary. "Algarin had a brother who could channel," he said, turning toward a facing chair. Halfway into the turn, he staggered. He caught himself on an arm of the chair with a barked laugh, pretending he had tripped over his own boots, but there had been no tripping. And he had not seized saidin - she had seen him stagger, doing that - or her ornaments would have warned her. Corele said he only needed a little more sleep to recover from Shadar Logoth. Light, she needed to keep the boy alive, or it had all been for nothing!

"aɪ noʊ," ʃi sɛd. ən sɪns ɪt simd ælɡɝɪn maɪɾ əv toʊld ɪm ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ʃi æɾəd, "aɪ wɑz ðə wʌn u kæptʃɝɾ əmɝɪn ən tʊk ɪm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn." ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋ fəɹ ælɡɝɪn tə bi ɡɹeɪtfəl fɔɹ, ɪn səm aɪz, bʌɾ ɪz jʌŋɡɝ bɹʌðɝ sɝvaɪv biɪŋ dʒɛntəl fəɹ mɔɹ ðən tɛn jɪɹz æftɝ ʃi hæd hɛlpt ɪm ɹɛkənsaɪl tə ɪt. ðə bɹʌðɝz hæd bɪn kloʊz.

"I know," she said. And since it seemed Algarin might have told him everything, she added, "I was the one who captured Emarin and took him to Tar Valon." A strange thing for Algarin to be grateful for, in some eyes, but his younger brother survived being gentled for more than ten years after she had helped him reconcile to it. The brothers had been close.

ðə bɔɪz aɪbɹaʊz twɪtʃt əz i sɛɾəld ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ. hi hæd nɑt noʊn. "ælɡɝɪn wɑns tə bi tɛstəd," hi sɛd. ʃi mɛɾ ɪz ɡeɪz lɛvəli, sɝinəli, ən hɛld əɹ tʌŋ. ælɡɝɪnz tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ mɛɹid, ðoʊz u stɪl lɪvd. meɪbi hi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə tɝn ðɪs pis ə læn oʊvɝ tə hɪz dɪsɛndəns. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wʌn mæn mɔɹ əɹ lɛs u kəd tʃænəl hɑɹdli meɪɾ ɛni dɪfɝəns ət ðɪs pɔɪnt. ənlɛs ɪt wɑz ðə bɔɪ hu wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ.

The boy's eyebrows twitched as he settled into his chair. He had not known. "Algarin wants to be tested," he said. She met his gaze levelly, serenely, and held her tongue. Algarin's children were married, those who still lived. Maybe he was ready to turn this piece of land over to his descendants. In any case, one man more or less who could channel hardly made any difference at this point. Unless it was the boy who was staring at her.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hɪz tʃɪn muvd, ðə vɛstɪdʒ ʌv ə nɑd. hæɾ i bɪn tɛstɪŋ hɝ? "nɛvɝ fɪɹ ðəɾ əl feɪl tə tɛl jə wən jəɹ biɪŋ ə ful, bɔɪ." moʊs pipəl ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðəɾ æftɝ wʌn miɾɪŋ ʃi hæɾ ə ʃɑɹp tʌŋ. ðɪs jʌŋ mæn ɹikwaɪɝd ɹimaɪndɪŋ fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm. hi ɡɹʌntɪd. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə læf. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ɹufəl. ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf ðəɾ i wɑntəɾ əɹ tə titʃ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊ wʌt. noʊ mæɾɝ. ʃi hæɾ ə lɪs tə tʃuz fɹʌm, ən ʃi hæɾ oʊnli bɪɡʌn ɑn ɪt. hɪz feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm stoʊn fəɹ ɔl ði ɪkspɹɛʃən i ʃoʊd, bʌɾ i baʊndəd tə hɪz fiɾ ən bɪɡæn tə peɪs bæk ən fɔɹθ bɪtwin ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən ðə dɔɹ. hɪz hænz wɝ klɛntʃt ɪn fɪsts bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. "aɪv bɪn tɔkɪŋ wɪð əliviə, əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn," hi sɛd. "ðeɪ kɔl ðɛɹ ɑɹmi ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi fəɹ ə ɹizən. ɪts nɛvɝ lɔst ə wɔɹ. bæɾəlz, jɛs, bʌt nɛvɝ ə wɔɹ.

After a moment, his chin moved, the vestige of a nod. Had he been testing her? "Never fear that I'll fail to tell you when you're being a fool, boy." Most people remembered that after one meeting she had a sharp tongue. This young man required reminding from time to time. He grunted. It might have been a laugh. It might have been rueful. She reminded herself that he wanted her to teach him something, though he did not seem to know what. No matter. She had a list to choose from, and she had only begun on it. His face might have been carved from stone for all the expression he showed, but he bounded to his feet and began to pace back and forth between the fireplace and the door. His hands were clenched in fists behind his back. "I've been talking with Alivia, about the Seanchan," he said. "They call their army the Ever Victorious Army for a reason. It's never lost a war. Battles, yes, but never a war.

wən ðeɪ luz ə bæɾəl, ðeɪ sɪt daʊn ən wɝk aʊt wʌt ðeɪ dɪd ɹɔŋ, əɹ wʌt ði ɛnəmi dɪd ɹaɪt.

When they lose a battle, they sit down and work out what they did wrong, or what the enemy did right.

ðən ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒ wʌt nidz tʃeɪnʒɪŋ fəɹ əm tə wɪn."

Then they change what needs changing for them to win."

"ə waɪz weɪ," ʃi sɛd wən ðə floʊ ʌv wɝdz pɔzd. pleɪnli, hi ɪkspɛktəd səm kɑmɛnt. "aɪ noʊ mɛn u də ðə seɪm. dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ, fəɹ wʌn. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn, ɹoʊɾəl ɪɾɝɑldi, eɪɡəlmɝ dʒəɡəd.

"A wise way," she said when the flow of words paused. Plainly, he expected some comment. "I know men who do the same. Davram Bashere, for one. Gareth Bryne, Rodel Ituralde, Agelmar Jagad.

ivən peɪdʒɹən naɪl dɪd, wən i wɑz əlaɪv. ɔl dʒʌdʒd ɡɹeɪt kæptənz."

Even Pedron Niall did, when he was alive. All judged great captains."

"jɛs," hi sɛd, stɪl peɪsɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət hɝ, pɝhæps dɪd nɑt si hɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz lɪsnɪŋ.

"Yes," he said, still pacing. He did not look at her, perhaps did not see her, but he was listening.

ɪt wɑz tə bi hoʊp ðəɾ i æktʃəli  hɝd, əz wɛl. "faɪv mɛn, ɔl ɡɹeɪt kæptənz. ðə sintʃæn ɔl də ɪt.

It was to be hoped that he actually heard, as well. "Five men, all great captains. The Seanchan all do it.

ðæts bɪn ðɛɹ weɪ fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz. ðeɪ tʃeɪnʒ wʌt ðeɪv tə tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt ðeɪ doʊnt ɡɪv ʌp."

That's been their way for a thousand years. They change what they have to change, but they don't give up."

"ɑɹ jə kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðeɪ kæn bi dɪfiɾəd?" ʃi æskt kɑmli. kɑmnəs ɔlweɪz suɾəd əntɪl jə nu ðə fæks, ən juʒəwəli æftɝ, tu.

"Are you considering the possibility they can't be defeated?" she asked calmly. Calmness always suited until you knew the facts, and usually after, too.

ðə bɔɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɝ, stɪf-nɛkt ən aɪz laɪk aɪs. "aɪ kən dɪfiɾ əm ɪvɛntʃəwəli," hi sɛd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kip ɪz toʊn sɪvəl. ðət mʌtʃ wɑz tə ðə ɡʊd. ðə lɛs ɔfən ʃi hæd tə pɹuv ðət ʃi kəɾ ən wəd pʌnɪʃ tʃɹænzɡɹɛʃənz ə hɝ ɹulz, ðə bɛɾɝ. "bʌt - " hi kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ə ɡɹaʊl əz ðə saʊnz ʌv ɑɹɡjəmən ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd ðə dɔɹ.

The boy rounded on her, stiff-necked and eyes like ice. "I can defeat them eventually," he said, struggling to keep his tone civil. That much was to the good. The less often she had to prove that she could and would punish transgressions of her rules, the better. "But - " He cut off with a growl as the sounds of argument in the hallway penetrated the door.

ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ oʊpən, ən ɛlzə bækt ɪndə ðə ɹum, stɪl ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɪn ə laʊd vɔɪs ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊl bæk tu ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɪð əɹ spɹɛɾ ɑɹmz. bɹaɪən, hɝ peɪl feɪs flʌʃt wɪð kʌlɝ, wɑz pʊʃɪŋ ði ʌðɝ ɡɹin əhɛɾ ə hɝ fɪzɪkəli. sɝin, ə wʊmən soʊ bjuɾəfəl ʃi meɪd bɹaɪən lʊk ɔlmoʊst ɔɹɾənɛɹi, wɔɹ ə kulɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən, əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm ə waɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən, ən hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə kʌlɝfəl bidz ɪn əɹ θɪn bɹeɪdz klɪk təɡɛðɝ. sɝin pəzɛst ə tɛmpɝ, ðoʊ ʃi nɔɹməli kɛpt ɪt sild əweɪ taɪtli. "bɑɹɾəl ən ɹæʃən də bi kʌmɪŋ," bɹaɪən ənaʊns laʊdli, ædʒəteɪʃən θɪkənɪŋ ɪljən ɪn əɹ spitʃ. ðoʊz wɝ əɹ tu wɔɹɾɝz, lɛf bɪhaɪn ɪn kɛɹhin. "aɪ dɪd noʊ sɛn fəɹ ðɛm, bʌt sʌmwʌn dɪd tʃɹævəl wɪð ðɛm. ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ, aɪ fɛlt əm sʌɾənli kloʊsɝ, ən dʒʌs naʊ, kloʊsɝ əɡɛn. ðeɪ ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əs naʊ." "maɪ vaɪɾəliən, hi ɔlsoʊ ɪz kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ," sɝin sɛd. "hi wɪl bi hɪɹ ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, aɪ θɪŋk." ɛlzə lɛɾ əɹ ɑɹmz dʒɹɑp, ðoʊ fɹəm ðə stɪfnəs ə hɝ bæk, ʃi wɑz stɪl ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə tu sɪstɝz. "maɪ fɝəl wɪl bi hɪɹ ʃɔɹtli əz wɛl," ʃi mʌɾɝd. hi wɑz əɹ oʊnli wɔɹɾɝ; ɪt wɑz sɛd ðeɪ wɝ mɛɹid, ən ɡɹinz u mɛɹid sɛldəm tʊk ənʌðɝ ənʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. kædzueɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wʊɾə spoʊkən ɪf ði ʌðɝz hæd nɑt.

A moment later the door swung open, and Elza backed into the room, still arguing in a loud voice and trying to hold back two other sisters with her spread arms. Brian, her pale face flushed with color, was pushing the other Green ahead of her physically. Sarene, a woman so beautiful she made Brian look almost ordinary, wore a cooler expression, as might be expected from a White, but she was shaking her head in exasperation, and hard enough to make the colorful beads in her thin braids click together. Sarene possessed a temper, though she normally kept it sealed away tightly. "Bartol and Rashan do be coming," Brian announced loudly, agitation thickening Illian in her speech. Those were her two Warders, left behind in Cairhien. "I did no send for them, but someone did Travel with them. An hour ago, I felt them suddenly closer, and just now, closer again. They are coming toward us now." "My Vitalien, he also is coming closer," Sarene said. "He will be here in a few hours, I think." Elza let her arms drop, though from the stiffness of her back, she was still glaring at the two sisters. "My Fearil will be here shortly as well," she muttered. He was her only Warder; it was said they were married, and Greens who married seldom took another another Warder at the same time. Cadsuane wondered whether she would have spoken if the others had not.

"aɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛkt ɪt soʊ sun," ðə bɔɪ sɛd sɔfli. sɔfli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stil ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "bʌɾ aɪ ʃʊdn əv ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪvɛns tə weɪɾ ɑn mi, ʃəɾ aɪ, kædzueɪn?"

"I didn't expect it so soon," the boy said softly. Softly, but there was steel in his voice. "But I shouldn't have expected events to wait on me, should I, Cadsuane?"

"ɪvɛns nɛvɝ weɪɾ ɑn ɛniwʌn," ʃi sɛd, stændɪŋ. bɹaɪən flɪntʃt əz ɪf ʃi hæd dʒʌs noʊɾəst hɝ, ðoʊ kædzueɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ əɹ feɪs wɑz əz smuð əz ðə bɔɪz. ən meɪbi əz stoʊni, ət ðæt. wʌt hæd bɹɔt ðoʊz wɔɹɾɝz fɹəm kɛɹhin, ən u hæd tʃɹævəld wɪð ðɛm, maɪt bi pɹɑbləmz ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð, bʌt ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən ənʌðɝ ænsɝ fɹəm ðə bɔɪ, ən ʃi wɑz gɑnə hæv tə kənsɪɾɝ vɛɹi kɛɹfəli haʊ tə ædvaɪz ɪm ɑn ɪt. səmtaɪmz, ði ænsɝz wɝ θɔɹniɝ ðən ðə kwɛstʃənz.

"Events never wait on anyone," she said, standing. Brian flinched as if she had just noticed her, though Cadsuane was sure her face was as smooth as the boy's. And maybe as stony, at that. What had brought those Warders from Cairhien, and who had Traveled with them, might be problems enough to go on with, but she thought she had gotten another answer from the boy, and she was going to have to consider very carefully how to advise him on it. Sometimes, the answers were thornier than the questions.

tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ

CHAPTER 24

eɪ stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ stɔɹm mɪdæftɝnun sʌnlaɪt ʃʊɾə bɪn slæntɪŋ θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz ə ɹændz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, bʌɾ ə hɑɹd ɹeɪn wɑz fɔlɪŋ aʊtsaɪd, ən ɔl ðə læmps wɝ lɪt tə hoʊld ɔf ə twaɪlaɪt dɑɹknəs. θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ðə ɡlæs-fɪl keɪsməns ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz. ɪt wɑz ə fɪɹs stɔɹm ðət hæd ɹoʊl daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl fæstɝ ðən ə ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹs ən bɹɔɾ ə dipɝ koʊld, ɔlmoʊs dip ɪnʌf fəɹ snoʊ. ðə ɹeɪndʒɹɑps pɛltɪŋ ðə haʊs wɝ hæf-fɹoʊzən slʌʃ, ən dɪspaɪt bleɪzɪŋ lɔɡz ɑn ðə hɑɹθstoʊn, ə tʃɪl klʌŋ tə ðə ɹum.

A Strengthening Storm Midafternoon sunlight should have been slanting through the windows of Rand's bedchamber, but a hard rain was falling outside, and all the lamps were lit to hold off a twilight darkness. Thunder rattled the glass-filled casements in the windows. It was a fierce storm that had rolled down out of the Dragonwall faster than a running horse and brought a deeper cold, almost deep enough for snow. The raindrops pelting the house were half-frozen slush, and despite blazing logs on the hearthstone, a chill clung to the room.

laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɛd wɪð ɪz buɾɪd fit pɹɑpt wʌn ətɑp ði ʌðɝ ɑn ðə kʌvɝlət, hi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ðə kænəpi ən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ɪz θɔts ɪn ɔɹɾɝ. hi kəd dɪsɹɪɡɑɹd ðə θʌndɝstɔɹm aʊtsaɪd, bʌt mɪn, snʌɡəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm, wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə dɪstʃɹæk hɪm; ʃi dʒʌs dɪɾ ɪt wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ. wʌt wɑz i tə də əbaʊt hɝ? əbaʊɾ ɪleɪn, ən eɪvinhə. ðoʊz tu wɝ oʊnli veɪɡ pɹɛzənsɪz ɪn ɪz hɛd, ət ðɪs dɪstəns fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn.

Lying on his bed with his booted feet propped one atop the other on the coverlet, he stared up at the canopy and tried to put his thoughts in order. He could disregard the thunderstorm outside, but Min, snuggling under his arm, was another matter. She did not try to distract him; she just did it without trying. What was he to do about her? About Elayne, and Aviendha. Those two were only vague presences in his head, at this distance from Caemlyn.

ət list, hi əsum ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. əsumɪŋ wɑz deɪnʒɝəs wən ɪt keɪm tə ðoʊz tu. ɔl i hæɾ ə ðɛm ət ðə moʊmənt wɑz ə dʒɛnɝəl sɛns ə dɝɛkʃən ən ðə nɑlədʒ ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪv. mɪnz bɑɾi wɑz pɹɛs taɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪz saɪd, ðoʊ, ən ðə bɑn meɪɾ əɹ əz vaɪbɹən ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛɾ əz ʃi wɑz ɪn ðə flɛʃ. wɑz ɪt tu leɪt tə kip mɪn seɪf, tə kip ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə seɪf?

At least, he assumed they were still in Caemlyn. Assuming was dangerous when it came to those two. All he had of them at the moment was a general sense of direction and the knowledge they were alive. Min's body was pressed tight against his side, though, and the bond made her as vibrant inside his head as she was in the flesh. Was it too late to keep Min safe, to keep Elayne and Aviendha safe?

wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk jə kən kip ɛniwʌn seɪf? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðə dɛd mædmæn wɑz ən oʊl fɹɛnd, naʊ. wəɹ ɔl ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. dʒʌs hoʊp ðət jə ɑɹən ðə wʌn u kɪlz ðɛm. nɑɾ ə wɛlkəm fɹɛnd, dʒʌst wʌn i kəd nɑt ɹɪd hɪmsɛlf ʌv. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɪɹd kɪlɪŋ mɪn əɹ ɪleɪn əɹ eɪvinhə ɛni mɔɹ ðən i fɪɹd ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. mæɾɝ ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz, ət list, wɪð ə dɛd mæn ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən səmtaɪmz ə fɑɡi feɪs i kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹɛkəɡnaɪz. dɪɾ i dɛɹ æsk kædzueɪn əbaʊɾ iðɝ wʌn?

What makes you think you can keep anyone safe? Lews Therin whispered in his head. The dead madman was an old friend, now. We are all going to die. Just hope that you aren't the one who kills them. Not a welcome friend, just one he could not rid himself of. He no longer feared killing Min or Elayne or Aviendha any more than he feared going mad. Madder than he already was, at least, with a dead man in his head, and sometimes a foggy face he could almost recognize. Did he dare ask Cadsuane about either one?

tʃɹʌs noʊ wʌn, lu θɝɪn mɝmɝd, ðən ɡeɪv ə ɹaɪ læf. ɪnkluɾɪŋ mi.

Trust no one, Lew Therin murmured, then gave a wry laugh. Including me.

wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, mɪn pʌntʃt ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm ɡɹʌnt. "jɔɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ mɛlənkɑli, ʃifɝɾɝ," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "ɪf jəɹ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt mi əɡɛn, aɪ swɛɹ, aɪl. . . . " ʃi hæd soʊ mɛni dɪfɹənt weɪz ʌv ɡɹoʊlɪŋ, mɪn dɪd, itʃ mætʃt tə vɛɹi dɪfɹən sɛnseɪʃənz θɹu ðə bɑnd. ðəɹ wɑz ðə laɪɾ ɪɹɪteɪʃən i fɛl fɹəm əɹ naʊ, ðɪs taɪm tʌtʃt wɪð wɝi, ən səmtaɪmz ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɑɹp ɛdʒ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɹɪfɹeɪnɪŋ fɹəm snæpɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɔf. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹaʊl ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪm læf fɹəm ði əmjuzmən ɪn əɹ hɛd, əɹ əz kloʊs tə læfɪŋ əz i hæd kʌm ɪn wʌt simd ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm, ən ə θɹoʊɾi ɡɹaʊl ðət wʊɾə hiɾəd ɪz blʌɾ ivən wɪθaʊt ðə bɑnd.

Without warning, Min punched him in the ribs hard enough to make him grunt. "You're getting melancholy, sheepherder," she growled. "If you're worrying about me again, I swear, I'll. . . . " She had so many different ways of growling, Min did, each matched to very different sensations through the bond. There was the light irritation he felt from her now, this time touched with worry, and sometimes there was a sharp edge as if she were refraining from snapping his head off. There was a growl that almost made him laugh from the amusement in her head, or as close to laughing as he had come in what seemed a very long time, and a throaty growl that would have heated his blood even without the bond.

"nʌn ə ðæt, naʊ," ʃi sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli, bɪfɔɹ i kəd muv ðə hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn əɹ bæk, ən ɹoʊld ɔf ðə bɛd tə hɝ fit, tʌɡɪŋ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊt stʃɹeɪt wɪð ə ɹipɹoʊvɪŋ lʊk. sɪns bɑndɪŋ hɪm, ʃi wɑz ivən bɛɾɝ ət ɹiɾɪŋ ɪz maɪnd, ən ʃi hæd bɪn ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf bɪfɔɹ. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə gɑnə də əbaʊt ðɛm, ɹænd? wʌɾ ɪz kædzueɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?" laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz, ɔlmoʊs bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə wɑʃ aʊt ðə læmps, ən θʌndɝ bumd əɡɛns ðə wɪndoʊ ɡlæs.

"None of that, now," she said warningly, before he could move the hand resting on her back, and rolled off the bed to her feet, tugging her embroidered coat straight with a reproving look. Since bonding him, she was even better at reading his mind, and she had been good enough before. "What are you going to do about them, Rand? What is Cadsuane going to do?" Lightning flashed in the windows, almost bright enough to wash out the lamps, and thunder boomed against the window glass.

"aɪ hævən jɛt bɪn eɪbəl tə si wʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə də əhɛɾ ə taɪm, mɪn. waɪ ʃəd tədeɪ bi dɪfɹənt?"

"I haven't yet been able to see what she was going to do ahead of time, Min. Why should today be different?"

ðə θɪk fɛðɝ mætʃɹəs sæɡd bɪniθ ɪm əz i swʌŋ ɪz lɛɡz oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ən sæɾ ʌp feɪsɪŋ hɝ. hi ɔlmoʊs pɹɛst ə hæn tə ði oʊld wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, ðən kɑt hɪmsɛlf ən tʃeɪnʒd ðə muvmən tə bʌtoʊnɪŋ ʌp ɪz koʊt. hæf-hild ən nɛvɝ hilɪŋ, ðoʊz tu oʊvɝlæpɪŋ wunz hɝt sɪns ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. əɹ meɪbi hi wɑz dʒʌs mɔɹ əwɛɹ ə haʊ ðeɪ θɹɑbd, ðə hiɾ ə ðɛm ə fɝnəs ə fivɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ən ɛɹiə smɔlɝ ðən ðə pɑm ə hɪz hænd. wʌn, ət list, hi hoʊpt, wəd bɪɡɪn tə hil wɪð ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɡɔn. meɪbi ðəɹ hæd dʒʌs nɑt bɪn ɪnʌf taɪm jɛt fəɹ ɪm tə fil ɛni dɪfɝəns. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm saɪd ðət mɪn hæd fɪstɪd - ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz dʒɛntəl wɪð ðæt, ɪf nɑɾ ɔlweɪz wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm - bʌɾ i θɔɾ i hæd kɛp ðə peɪn hɪɾən fɹəm hɝ. noʊ pɔɪn ɪn ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ tə wɝi oʊvɝ. ðə kənsɝn ɪn əɹ aɪz, ən ɪn əɹ hɛd, mʌs bi əbaʊt kædzueɪn. əɹ ði ʌðɝz.

The thick feather mattress sagged beneath him as he swung his legs over the side and sat up facing her. He almost pressed a hand to the old wounds in his side without thinking, then caught himself and changed the movement to buttoning up his coat. Half-healed and never healing, those two overlapping wounds hurt since Shadar Logoth. Or maybe he was just more aware of how they throbbed, the heat of them a furnace of fever trapped in an area smaller than the palm of his hand. One, at least, he hoped, would begin to heal with Shadar Logoth gone. Maybe there had just not been enough time yet for him to feel any difference. It was not the same side that Min had fisted - she was always gentle with that, if not always with the rest of him - but he thought he had kept the pain hidden from her. No point in giving her something more to worry over. The concern in her eyes, and in her head, must be about Cadsuane. Or the others.

ðə mænɝ haʊs ən ɔl ʌv ɪts aʊtlaɪɪŋ bɪldɪŋz wɝ kɹaʊɾəd, naʊ. ɪt hæd simd ɪnɛvəɾəbəl ðət sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ sʌmwʌn wəd tʃɹaɪ juzɪŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝz lɛft ɪn kɛɹhin; ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt blɛɹd ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt niðɝ hæd ðeɪ bɪn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli sikɹəɾɪv.

The manor house and all of its outlying buildings were crowded, now. It had seemed inevitable that sooner or later someone would try using the Warders left in Cairhien; their Aes Sedai had not blared that they were going off to find the Dragon Reborn, but neither had they been particularly secretive.

ivən soʊ, hi hæd nɛvɝ æntɪsəpeɪɾəd ðoʊz u ɝaɪvd wɪð ðɛm. dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ə hɪz sɑldəiən laɪt hɔɹs, dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ɪn ə wɪndʒɹaɪvən soʊkɪŋ ɹeɪn ən mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt ɹuən sæɾəlz.

Even so, he had never anticipated those who arrived with them. Davram Bashere with a hundred of his Saldaean light horse, dismounting in a winddriven soaking rain and muttering about ruined saddles.

oʊvɝ hæf ə dʌzən blæk-koʊɾəd æʃəmən u fəɹ səm ɹizən hæd nɑt ʃildɪd ðɛmsɛlvz fɹəm ðə daʊnpɔɹ. ðeɪ ɹoʊd wɪð bæʃɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk tu pɑɹɾiz ɝaɪvɪŋ, ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns bɪtwin əm ɔlweɪz, ə stʃɹɔŋ wɪf ʌv wɑtʃfəl wɛɹinɪs. ən wʌn ə ði æʃəmən wɑz lɑɡən əblɝ. lɑɡən!

Over half a dozen black-coated Asha'man who for some reason had not shielded themselves from the downpour. They rode with Bashere, but it had been like two parties arriving, a little distance between them always, a strong whiff of watchful wariness. And one of the Asha'man was Logain Ablar. Logain!

ən æʃəmən, wɛɹɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ən dʒɹæɡən ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ! bæʃɪɹ ən lɑɡən boʊθ wɑntəd tə tɔk tə hɪm, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛniwʌn, ɪspɛʃli itʃ ʌðɝ ɪt simd. ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ əɹ nɑt, ðoʊ, ðeɪ wɝ hɑɹdli ðə moʊst sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ ə ðə vɪzəɾɝz. hi hæd θɔt ði eɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌs bi mɔɹ fɹɛnz ə kædzueɪn, jɛɾ i wəd swɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn əz sɝpɹaɪzd əz i tə si moʊst ə ðɛm. ɑɾɝ, ɔl bʌt wʌn sim tə bi wɪð ði æʃəmən! nɑt pɹɪznɝz, ən sɝɾənli nɑt ɡɑɹdz, bʌt lɑɡən hæd bɪn ɹɪlʌktən tə ɪkspleɪn wɪð bæʃɪɹ pɹɛzənt, ən bæʃɪɹ ɹɪlʌktən tə liv lɑɡən ðə fɝs tʃæns tə tɔk tə ɹænd əloʊn. naʊ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dʒɹaɪɪŋ ɔf ən sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ ɹumz, livɪŋ ɪm tə tʃɹaɪ tə pʊɾ ɪz θɔts ɪn ɔɹɾɝ. tə ði ɪkstɛn ðəɾ i kʊd, wɪð mɪn kloʊs baɪ. wʌt wəd kædzueɪn du? wɛl, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə æsk əɹ ædvaɪs. ɪvɛns hæɾ aʊtʃɹʌn boʊθ ə ðɛm, ðoʊ. ðə dɪsɪʒən hæd bɪn meɪd, wʌtɛvɝ kædzueɪn θɔt. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt əɡɛn ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz. laɪtnɪŋ sim tə sut kædzueɪn. jə kəd nɛvɝ tɛl wɛɹ ɪt wəd stʃɹaɪk.

An Asha'man, wearing the Sword and Dragon on his collar! Bashere and Logain both wanted to talk to him, but not in front of anyone, especially each other it seemed. Unexpected or not, though, they were hardly the most surprising of the visitors. He had thought the eight Aes Sedai must be more friends of Cadsuane, yet he would swear she had been as surprised as he to see most of them. Odder, all but one seemed to be with the Asha'man! Not prisoners, and certainly not guards, but Logain had been reluctant to explain with Bashere present, and Bashere reluctant to leave Logain the first chance to talk to Rand alone. Now they were all drying off and settling into their rooms, leaving him to try to put his thoughts in order. To the extent that he could, with Min close by. What would Cadsuane do? Well, he had tried to ask her advice. Events had outrun both of them, though. The decision had been made, whatever Cadsuane thought. Lightning flashed again in the windows. Lightning seemed to suit Cadsuane. You could never tell where it would strike.

əliviə wəd fɪnɪʃ hɝ, luz θɝɪn mʌɾɝd. ʃiz gɑnə hɛlp əs daɪ; ʃid ɹimuv kædzueɪn fəɹ ʌs, ɪf jə tɛl əɹ tə.

Alivia would finish her, Lews Therin muttered. She's going to help us die; she'd remove Cadsuane for us, if you tell her to.

aɪ doʊnt wɑnə kɪl hɝ. ɹænd θɔɾ ət ðə dɛd mæn. aɪ kæn əfɔɹd fəɹ əɹ tə daɪ. luz θɝɪn nu ðəɾ əz wɛl əz hi, bʌt ðə mæn ɡɹʌmbəld ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ ɛniweɪ. sɪns ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, hi simd ə tʌtʃ lɛs mæd, səmtaɪmz. əɹ meɪbi ɹænd wɑz ə tʌtʃ mɔɹ. æftɝ ɔl, hi tʊk tɔkɪŋ tə ə dɛd mæn ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əz ə mæɾɝ ʌv ɛvɹi deɪ, ən ðət wɑz hɑɹdli seɪn.

I don't want to kill her. Rand thought at the dead man. I can't afford for her to die. Lews Therin knew that as well as he, but the man grumbled under his breath anyway. Since Shadar Logoth, he seemed a touch less mad, sometimes. Or maybe Rand was a touch more. After all, he took talking to a dead man in his head as a matter of every day, and that was hardly sane.

"ju hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ" mɪn mʌɾɝd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. "lɑɡənz ɔɹə stɪl spiks ʌv ɡlɔɹi, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛvɝ. meɪbi hi stɪl θɪŋks hiz ðə ɹil dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ən ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ . . . dɑɹk . . . ɪn ði ɪmədʒəz aɪ sɔ ɝaʊn lɔɹd dævɹæm. ɪf i tɝnz əɡɛns ju, əɹ daɪz. . . . aɪ hɝd wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz seɪ lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn maɪt daɪ. luzɪŋ ivən wʌn ə ðɛm wəd bi ə bloʊ. luz ɔl θɹi, ən ɪt maɪt teɪk jə ə jɪɹ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ." "ɪf juv sin ɪt, ðən ɪts ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən. aɪ hæv tə də wʌɾ aɪ kæn, mɪn, nɑt wɝi oʊvɝ wʌɾ aɪ kænt." ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm wʌn ə ðoʊz lʊks wɪmən hæɾ ɪn ɡɹeɪt stɔɹ, əz ɪf i wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑɹɾ ən ɑɹɡjəmənt.

"You have to do something" Min muttered, folding her arms beneath her breasts. "Logain's aura still speaks of glory, stronger than ever. Maybe he still thinks he's the real Dragon Reborn. And there's something . . . dark . . . in the images I saw around Lord Davram. If he turns against you, or dies. . . . I heard one of the soldiers say Lord Dobraine might die. Losing even one of them would be a blow. Lose all three, and it might take you a year to recover." "If you've seen it, then it's going to happen. I have to do what I can, Min, not worry over what I can't." She gave him one of those looks women had in great store, as if he were trying to start an argument.

ə skɹætʃɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ bɹɔɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɝaʊn ən meɪd mɪn ʃɪft əɹ stæns. hi səspɛktəd ʃi hæd slɪpt ə θɹoʊɪŋ naɪf aʊɾ ə hɝ sliv ən wɑz haɪɾɪŋ ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ ɹɪst. ðə wʊmən kæɹid mɔɹ naɪvz tʌkt əbaʊɾ əɹ ðən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hæd. əɹ mæt. kʌlɝz wɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd, ɔlmoʊst ɹizɑlvɪŋ ɪndə . . . wʌt? ə mæn ɑn ə wæɡən sit? nɑt ðə feɪs ðət səmtaɪmz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz θɔts, ɛniweɪ, ən ðə sin wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən ɪnstənt, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ðə dɪzinəs ðəɾ əkʌmpənid ðə feɪs. "kʌm," hi kɔld, stændɪŋ ʌp.

A scratching at the door brought his head around and made Min shift her stance. He suspected she had slipped a throwing knife out of her sleeve and was hiding it behind her wrist. The woman carried more knives tucked about her than Thom Merrilin had. Or Mat. Colors whirled in his head, almost resolving into . . . what? A man on a wagon seat? Not the face that sometimes appeared in his thoughts, anyway, and the scene was gone in an instant, without any of the dizziness that accompanied the face. "Come," he called, standing up.

ɛlzə spɹɛɾ əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin skɝts ɪn ən ɛləɡən kɝtsi wən ʃi ɛntɝd, hɝ aɪz bɹaɪɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. ə plɛzənt-əpɪɹɪŋ wʊmən, ən kuli kəmpleɪsən əz ə kæt, ʃi hɑɹdli sim tə si mɪn. ʌv ɔl ðə sɪstɝz u hæd swɔɹn tə hɪm, ɛlzə wɑz ðə moʊst iɡɝ. ði oʊnli iɡɝ wʌn, ɹɪli. ði ʌðɝz hæd ðɛɹ ɹizənz fəɹ swɛɹɪŋ, ðɛɹ ɛkspləneɪʃənz, ən ə kɔɹs vɛɹɪn ən ðə sɪstɝz u keɪm tə faɪn ɪm ət dəməaɪz wɛlz hæd noʊ ɹil tʃɔɪs feɪsɪŋ ə tɑvɝən, bʌt fəɹ ɔl ɛlzəz aʊɾɝ kulnəs, ʃi sim tə bɝn ɪnsaɪd wɪð ə pæʃən tə si hi ɹitʃt tɑɹmən ɡdən. "ju sɛd tə lɛt jə noʊ wən ði oʊɡiɝ keɪm," ʃi sɛd, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ɪz feɪs.

Elza spread her dark green skirts in an elegant curtsy when she entered, her eyes bright on his face. A pleasant-appearing woman, and coolly complacent as a cat, she hardly seemed to see Min. Of all the sisters who had sworn to him, Elza was the most eager. The only eager one, really. The others had their reasons for swearing, their explanations, and of course Verin and the sisters who came to find him at Dumai's Wells had no real choice facing a ta'veren, but for all Elza's outer coolness, she seemed to burn inside with a passion to see he reached Tarmon Gai'don. "You said to let you know when the Ogier came," she said, never taking her eyes from his face.

"lɔɪəl!" mɪn ʃaʊɾəd ɡlifəli, tʌkɪŋ ðə naɪf bæk ʌp əɹ sliv əz ʃi ɹʌʃt pæst ɛlzə, hu blɪŋkt ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bleɪd. "aɪ cʊɾə kɪld ɹænd fəɹ lɛɾɪŋ jə ɡɛɾ ɔf tə jəɹ ɹum bɪfɔɹ aɪ sɔ ju!" ðə bɑn sɛd ʃi dɪd nɑt min ɪt. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli.

"Loial!" Min shouted gleefully, tucking the knife back up her sleeve as she rushed past Elza, who blinked at the sight of the blade. "I could have killed Rand for letting you get off to your room before I saw you!" The bond said she did not mean it. Not exactly.

"θæŋk ju," ɹænd toʊld ɛlzə, lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə saʊnz ə mɛɹəmən fɹəm ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, mɪnz laɪt læftɝ ən lɔɪəlz kweɪk ʌv oʊɡiɝ mɝθ, laɪk ði ɝθ læfɪŋ. θʌndɝ ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ.

"Thank you," Rand told Elza, listening to the sounds of merriment from the sitting room, Min's light laughter and Loial's quake of Ogier mirth, like the earth laughing. Thunder rolled across the sky.

pɝhæps ði ɛɛs sədaɪz pæʃən ɪkstɛndəd tə wɑntɪŋ tə noʊ wʌɾ i sɛd tə lɔɪəl, kəz əɹ lɪps θɪnd, ən ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ kɝtsi ən swipɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ. ə bɹif pɔz ɪn ðə saʊnz ə plɛʒɝ ənaʊnst əɹ pæsədʒ əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ən ðɛɹ ɹɪzʌmpʃən əɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. oʊnli ðən dɪɾ i siz ðə paʊɝ. hi tʃɹaɪd nɛvɝ tə lɛɾ ɛniwʌn si hɪm də ðæt.

Perhaps the Aes Sedai's passion extended to wanting to know what he said to Loial, because her lips thinned, and she hesitated before making another curtsy and sweeping out of the bedchamber. A brief pause in the sounds of pleasure announced her passage across the sitting room, and their resumption her departure. Only then did he seize the Power. He tried never to let anyone see him do that.

faɪɝ flʌɾəd ɪndə hɪm, hɑɾɝ ðən ðə sʌn, ən koʊl tə meɪk ðə wɝs blɪzɝd sim spɹɪŋ, ɔl ə swɝlɪŋ ɹeɪdʒ ðət dwɔɹf ðə stɔɹm aʊtsaɪd, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə skaʊɝ ɪm əweɪ fəɹ ə moʊməns ɪnətɛntʃən.

Fire flooded into him, hotter than the sun, and cold to make the worst blizzard seem spring, all a swirling rage that dwarfed the storm outside, threatening to scour him away for a moment's inattention.

sizɪŋ seɪɾɪn wɑz ə wɔɹ fəɹ sɝvaɪvəl. bʌt ðə ɡɹin ə ðə kɔɹnɪsəz wɑz sʌɾənli ɡɹinɝ, ðə blæk ə hɪz koʊt blækɝ, ðə ɡoʊld ʌv ɪts ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi mɔɹ ɡoʊldən. hi kəd si ðə ɡɹeɪn ə ðə vaɪn-kɑɹv bɪdpoʊsts, si feɪn mɑɹks lɛf baɪ ðə kɹæfsmənz sændɪŋ ɔl ðoʊz jɪɹz əɡoʊ. seɪɾɪn meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i hæd bɪn hæfblɪn ən nʌm wɪθaʊɾ ɪt. ðət wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ i fɛlt.

Seizing saidin was a war for survival. But the green of the cornices was suddenly greener, the black of his coat blacker, the gold of its embroidery more golden. He could see the grain of the vine-carved bedposts, see faint marks left by the craftsman's sanding all those years ago. Saidin made him feel as if he had been halfblind and numb without it. That was a part of what he felt.

klin, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. pjʊɹ ən klin əɡɛn.

Clean, Lews Therin whispered. Pure and clean again.

ɪt wɑz. ðə faʊlnəs ðət hæd mɑɹk ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ wɑz ɡɔn.

It was. The foulness that had marked the male half of the Power since the Breaking was gone.

ðət dɪd nɑt stɑp nɔziə fɹəm ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ɹænd, ðoʊ, ðə vaɪələn ɝdʒ tə bɛn dʌbəl ən ɛmpti hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə ɹum sim tə spɪn fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ən i hæd tə pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə nɪɹəs bɪdpoʊs tə stɛɾi hɪmsɛlf. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ hi ʃəd stɪl fil ðɪs sɪknəs, wɪð ðə teɪnt ɡɔn. luz θɝɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ, əɹ wəd nɑt tɛl. bʌt ðə sɪknəs wɑz ðə ɹizən i kəd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn si hɪm teɪk hoʊld ə seɪɾɪn, ɪf i kəd hɛlp ɪt. ɛlzə maɪt bɝn tə si hɪm ɹitʃ ðə læs bæɾəl, bʌt tu mɛni ʌðɝz wɑntəd tə si hɪm fɔl, nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

That did not stop nausea from rising in Rand, though, the violent urge to bend double and empty himself on the floor. The room seemed to spin for an instant, and he had to put a hand on the nearest bedpost to steady himself. He did not know why he should still feel this sickness, with the taint gone. Lews Therin did not know, or would not tell. But the sickness was the reason he could not let anyone see him take hold of saidin, if he could help it. Elza might burn to see him reach the Last Battle, but too many others wanted to see him fall, not all of them Darkfriends.

ɪn ðət moʊmən ʌv wiknəs, ðə dɛd mæn ɹitʃt fəɹ seɪɾɪn. ɹænd kəd fil ɪm klɔɪŋ fəɹ ɪt ɡɹiɾəli. wɑz ɪt hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɪt hæd bɪn tə pʊʃ ɪm əweɪ? ɪn səm weɪz, luz θɝɪn simd mɔɹ sɑlədli pɑɹɾ ə hɪm sɪns ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. hi hæɾ oʊnli soʊ fɑɹ lɛf tə ɡoʊ bɪfɔɹ i kəd daɪ. hi dʒʌs hæd tə læs ðət fɑɹ. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə lɪŋɡɝɪŋ tʃɹeɪsəz ə sɪknəs ɪn ɪz bɛli ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum tə ðə kɹæʃ ə θʌndɝ.

In that moment of weakness, the dead man reached for saidin. Rand could feel him clawing for it greedily. Was it harder than it had been to push him away? In some ways, Lews Therin seemed more solidly part of him since Shadar Logoth. It did not matter. He had only so far left to go before he could die. He just had to last that far. Drawing a deep breath, he ignored the lingering traces of sickness in his belly and strode into the sitting room to the crash of thunder.

mɪn stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum hoʊldɪŋ wʌn ə lɔɪəlz hænz ɪn boʊθ ə hɝz ən smaɪlɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm. ɪt tʊk boʊθ ə hɝ hænz tə hoʊld wʌn ə lɔɪəlz, ən ðə pɛɹ dɪd nɑt kʌm kloʊs tə kʌvɝɪŋ ɪt.

Min stood in the middle of the room holding one of Loial's hands in both of hers and smiling up at him. It took both of her hands to hold one of Loial's, and the pair did not come close to covering it.

ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd mɪs ðə plæstɝ silɪŋ baɪ lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə fʊt. hi hæd dɑn ə fɹɛʃ koʊɾ ə dɑɹk blu wʊl, ðə bɑɾəm flɛɹɪŋ oʊvɝ bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz tə ðə tɑps ə hɪz ni-haɪ buts, bʌt fəɹ wʌns ɪz pɑkəts dɪd nɑt bʌlʒ wɪð ði æŋɡjəlɝ ʃeɪps ə bʊks. aɪz ðə saɪz ə tikəps lɪɾ ʌp ət ðə saɪɾ ə ɹænd, ən ðə ɡɹɪn ɑn ɪz waɪd maʊθ ɹɪli dɪd splɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn tu. ðə tʌftəɾ ɪɹz stɪkɪŋ ʌp θɹu hɪz ʃæɡi hɛɹ kwɪvɝd wɪð plɛʒɝ. "lɔɹɾ ælɡɝɪn əz oʊɡiɝ ɡɛst ɹumz, ɹænd," hi bumd ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk ə dip dʒɹʌm. "kæn jə ɪmædʒən ɪt? sɪks ə ðɛm! ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ hævən bɪn juzd ɪn səm taɪm, bʌt ðəɹ ɛɹɾ aʊɾ ɛvɹi wik, soʊ ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni mʌstinəs, ən ðə bɛdʃits ɑɹ vɛɹi ɡʊd lɪnən. aɪ θɔɾ aɪd bi bæk tə dʌbəlɪŋ maɪsɛlf ʌp ɪn ə hjumən-saɪz bɛd. ʌm. wi ɑɹən steɪɪŋ hɪɹ lɔŋ, ɑɹ wi?" hɪz lɔŋ ɪɹz sæɡd ə lɪɾəl, ðən bɪɡæn tə twɪtʃ ənizəli. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi ʃʊd. aɪ min, aɪ maɪt ɡɛt juz tə hævɪŋ ə ɹil bɛd, ən ðət wʊdn də ɪf aɪm gɑnə steɪ wɪð ju. aɪ min. .

The top of his head missed the plaster ceiling by little more than a foot. He had donned a fresh coat of dark blue wool, the bottom flaring over baggy trousers to the tops of his knee-high boots, but for once his pockets did not bulge with the angular shapes of books. Eyes the size of teacups lit up at the sight of Rand, and the grin on his wide mouth really did split his face in two. The tufted ears sticking up through his shaggy hair quivered with pleasure. "Lord Algarin has Ogier guest rooms, Rand," he boomed in a voice like a deep drum. "Can you imagine it? Six of them! Of course, they haven't been used in some time, but they're aired out every week, so there isn't any mustiness, and the bedsheets are very good linen. I thought I'd be back to doubling myself up in a human-sized bed. Umm. We aren't staying here long, are we?" His long ears sagged a little, then began to twitch uneasily. "I don't think we should. I mean, I might get used to having a real bed, and that wouldn't do if I'm going to stay with you. I mean. .

. . wɛl, jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min."

. . Well, you know what I mean."

"aɪ noʊ," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. hi cʊɾə læft ət ði oʊɡiɝz kɑnstɝneɪʃən. hi ʃəɾ əv læft. læftɝ dʒʌst sim tə hæv ɪskeɪp hɪm, leɪtli. spɪnɪŋ ə wɛb əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, hi nɑɾɪd ɪt soʊ hi kəd ɹilis seɪɾɪn.

"I know," Rand said softly. He could have laughed at the Ogier's consternation. He should have laughed. Laughter just seemed to have escaped him, lately. Spinning a web against eavesdropping around the room, he knotted it so he could release saidin.

ðə læs tʃɹeɪsəz ə nɔziə bɪɡæn tə feɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli. hi kəd kɑn-tʃɹoʊl ðə sɪknəs, juʒəwəli, wɪð ən ɛfɝt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪnt wən i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə. "dɪɾ ɛni ʌv jəɹ bʊks ɡɛt wɛt?" lɔɪəlz meɪn kənsɝn kʌmɪŋ ɪn hæd bɪn tə tʃɛk ɑn ɪz bʊks. sʌɾənli ɪt stʃɹʌk ɪm ðəɾ i hæd θɔɾ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd dʌn əz spɪnɪŋ ə wɛb. ðət wɑz haʊ luz θɝɪn wəd pʊɾ ɪt. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ hæpən tu ɔfən, ði ʌðɝ mænz tɝnz ə fɹeɪz dʒɹɪftɪŋ ɪndə hɪz hɛd, ði ʌðɝ mænz mɛmɹiz mɪŋɡəlɪŋ wɪð hɪz. hi wɑz ɹænd ælθɹ, nɑt luz θɝɪn tɛləmən. hi hæd woʊvən ə wɔɹɾ ən taɪɾ ɔf ðə wiv, nɑt spʌn ə wɛb ən nɑɾɪd ɪt. bʌt ðə wʌn keɪm tə hɪm əz izəli əz ði ʌðɝ. "maɪ ɛseɪz ɑfwɪlɪm ə meɪnɪtʃɪz ɡɑt dæmp," lɔɪəl sɛd dɪsɡʌstɪdli, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ ðə θɪknəs ʌv ə sɔsədʒ. hæɾ i bɪn kɛɹləs ʃeɪvɪŋ, əɹ wɑz ðət ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʌv ə mʌstæʃ bɪniθ ɪz waɪd noʊz?

The last traces of nausea began to fade immediately. He could con-trol the sickness, usually, with an effort, but there was no point when he did not have to. "Did any of your books get wet?" Loial's main concern coming in had been to check on his books. Suddenly it struck him that he had thought of what he had done as spinning a web. That was how Lews Therin would put it. That sort of thing happened too often, the other man's turns of phrase drifting into his head, the other man's memories mingling with his. He was Rand al'Thor, not Lews Therin Telamon. He had woven a ward and tied off the weave, not spun a web and knotted it. But the one came to him as easily as the other. "My Essays ofWillim of Maneches got damp," Loial said disgustedly, rubbing his upper lip with a finger the thickness of a sausage. Had he been careless shaving, or was that the beginning of a mustache beneath his wide nose?

"ðə peɪdʒəz meɪ spɑt. aɪ ʃʊdn əv bɪn soʊ kɛɹləs, nɑt wɪð ə bʊk. ən maɪ bʊk ə noʊts tʊk səm wɛt, tu. bʌt ði ɪŋk dɪdn ɹʌn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz stɪl ɹiɾəbəl, bʌɾ aɪ ɹɪli nid tə meɪk ə keɪs tə pɹətɛkt. . . . " sloʊli, ə fɹaʊn kɹɛpt ɑntu hɪz feɪs, dæŋɡəlɪŋ ðə lɔŋ ɛnz ə hɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɑntu hɪz tʃiks. "ju lʊk taɪɝd, ɹænd. hi lʊks taɪɝd, mɪn." "hiz bɪn duɪŋ tu mʌtʃ, bʌt hiz ɹɛstɪŋ naʊ," mɪn sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli, ən ɹænd dɪd smaɪl. ə lɪɾəl. mɪn wəɾ ɔlweɪz dɪfɛn hɪm, ivən tə hɪz fɹɛnz.

"The pages may spot. I shouldn't have been so careless, not with a book. And my book of notes took some wet, too. But the ink didn't run. Everything is still readable, but I really need to make a case to protect. . . . " Slowly, a frown crept onto his face, dangling the long ends of his eyebrows onto his cheeks. "You look tired, Rand. He looks tired, Min." "He's been doing too much, but he's resting now," Min said defensively, and Rand did smile. A little. Min would always defend him, even to his friends.

"ju ɑɹ ɹɛstɪŋ, ʃifɝɾɝ," ʃi æɾəd, lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ʌv lɔɪəlz hjudʒ hæn ən plæntɪŋ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps. "sɪt daʊn ən ɹɛst. oʊ, sɪt daʊn, lɔɪəl. əl pʊɾ ə kɹɪk ɪn maɪ nɛk ɪf aɪ kip stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ju." lɔɪəl tʃʌkəld, ðə bɛloʊɪŋ ʌv ə bʊl mjuɾɪd ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, əz i ɪɡzæmənd wʌn ə ðə stʃɹeɪt-bæk tʃɛɹz dubiəsli. kəmpɛɹd tə hɪm, ɪt simd ə tʃɛɹ meɪd fəɹ ə tʃaɪld. "ʃifɝɾɝ. jə doʊnt noʊ haʊ ɡʊɾ ɪts tə hɪɹ jə kɔlɪŋ ɪm ʃifɝɾɝ, mɪn." hi sæt daʊn kɔʃəsli. ðə pleɪn-kɑɹv tʃɛɹ kɹikt ʌndɝ ɪz weɪt, ən ɪz niz stʌk ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. "aɪ æm sɑɹi, ɹænd, bʌɾ ɪts fʌni, ən aɪ hævən hɝd mʌtʃ tə læf ət ðiz pæs mʌnθs." ðə tʃɛɹ wɑz hoʊldɪŋ. wɪð ə kwɪk ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə hɔl dɔɹ, hi æɾəd, ə lɪɾəl tu laʊdli, "kɑɹldɪn dʌzn əv mʌtʃ sɛns ə hjumɝ."

"You are resting, sheepherder," she added, letting go of Loial's huge hand and planting her fists on her hips. "Sit down and rest. Oh, sit down, Loial. I'll put a crick in my neck if I keep staring up at you." Loial chuckled, the bellowing of a bull muted in his throat, as he examined one of the straight-back chairs dubiously. Compared to him, it seemed a chair made for a child. "Sheepherder. You don't know how good it is to hear you calling him sheepherder, Min." He sat down cautiously. The plain-carved chair creaked under his weight, and his knees stuck up in front of him. "I am sorry, Rand, but it is funny, and I haven't heard much to laugh at these past months." The chair was holding. With a quick glance toward the hall door, he added, a little too loudly, "Karldin doesn't have much sense of humor."

"ju kən spik fɹili," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. "wɝ seɪf bɪhaɪn ə . . . ə wɔɹd." hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊst sɛd bɪhaɪn ə ʃild, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm θɪŋ. ɪksɛp ðəɾ i nu ɪt wɑz.

"You can speak freely," Rand told him. "We're safe behind a . . . a ward." He had almost said behind a shield, which was not the same thing. Except that he knew it was.

hi wɑz tu wɪɹi tə sɪt, dʒʌst əz i wɑz tu taɪɝd tə faɪn slip izəli moʊs naɪts - hɪz boʊnz ætʃt wɪð ɪt - soʊ hi wɛn tə stæn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. wɪnz ɡʌstɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə tʃɪmni tɑp meɪd ðə fleɪmz dæns ɑn ðə splɪt lɔɡz ən səmtaɪmz lɛɾ ə smɔl pʌf ə smoʊk ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən i kəd hɪɹ ðə ɹeɪn dʒɹʌmɪŋ əweɪ ət ðə wɪndoʊz, bʌt ðə θʌndɝ sim tə hæv muvd ɑn. meɪbi ðə stɔɹm wɑz ɛndɪŋ. klæspɪŋ ɪz hænz bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, hi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə faɪɝ. "wʌt dɪd ði ɛldɝz seɪ, lɔɪəl?" ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ, lɔɪəl lʊkt ət mɪn əz ɪf sikɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmən əɹ səpɔɹt. pɝtʃt ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə blu ɑɹmtʃɛɹ wɪð əɹ niz kɹɔst, ʃi smaɪld ət ði oʊɡiɝ ən nɑɾəd, ən i saɪd hɛvəli, ə wɪnd ɡʌstɪŋ θɹu dip kævɝnz. "kɑɹldɪn ən aɪ vɪzəɾəd ɛvɹi stɛɾɪŋ, ɹænd. ɔl bʌt stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. aɪ kʊdnt ɡoʊ ðɛɹ, bʌɾ aɪ lɛft ə mɛsədʒ ɛvɹiwɛɹ wi wɛnt, ən deɪɾɪŋ ɪzən fɑɹ fɹəm ʃæŋktaɪ. sʌmwʌn wɪl kæɹi ɪt ðɛɹ. ðə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp ɪz miɾɪŋ ɪn ʃæŋktaɪ, ən ðət wɪl ətʃɹækt kɹaʊdz. ðɪs ɪz ðə fɝs taɪm ə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp əz bɪn kɔld ɪn ə θaʊzən jɪɹz, nɑt sɪns jə hjumənz fɔt ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ən ɪt wɑz ʃæŋktaɪz tɝn. ðeɪ mʌs bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt, bʌt noʊ wʌn wəd tɛl mi waɪ ɪt wɑz kɔld.

He was too weary to sit, just as he was too tired to find sleep easily most nights - his bones ached with it - so he went to stand in front of the fireplace. Winds gusting across the chimney top made the flames dance on the split logs and sometimes let a small puff of smoke into the room, and he could hear the rain drumming away at the windows, but the thunder seemed to have moved on. Maybe the storm was ending. Clasping his hands behind his back, he turned away from the fire. "What did the Elders say, Loial?" Instead of answering straightaway, Loial looked at Min as if seeking encouragement or support. Perched on the edge of a blue armchair with her knees crossed, she smiled at the Ogier and nodded, and he sighed heavily, a wind gusting through deep caverns. "Karldin and I visited every stedding, Rand. All but Stedding Shangtai, of course. I couldn't go there, but I left a message everywhere we went, and Daiting isn't far from Shangtai. Someone will carry it there. The Great Stump is meeting in Shangtai, and that will attract crowds. This is the first time a Great Stump has been called in a thousand years, not since you humans fought the War of the Hundred Years, and it was Shangtai's turn. They must be considering something very important, but no one would tell me why it was called.

ðeɪ woʊn tɛl jə əbaʊɾ ɛni stʌmp əntɪl juv ə bɪɹd," hi mʌɾɝd, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ə nɛɹoʊ pætʃ ə stʌbəl ɑn ɪz bɹɔd tʃɪn. əpɛɹənli, hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɛməɾi hɪz læk, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ðəɾ i kʊd. lɔɪəl wɑz oʊvɝ naɪnti jɪɹz oʊld, naʊ, jɛt fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ, ðət wɑz stɪl ə bɔɪ.

They won't tell you about any Stump until you have a beard," he muttered, fingering a narrow patch of stubble on his broad chin. Apparently, he intended to remedy his lack, though it was not certain that he could. Loial was over ninety years old, now, yet for an Ogier, that was still a boy.

"ði ɛldɝz?" ɹænd æsk peɪʃənli. jə hæd tə bi peɪʃənt wɪð lɔɪəl, wɪð ɛni oʊɡiɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si taɪm ðə weɪ hjumənz dɪd - hu əmʌŋ hjumənz wəd θɪŋk ə huz tɝn ɪt wɑz æftɝ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz? - ən lɔɪəl tɛndəd tə ɡoʊ ɑn ət lɛŋθ, ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns. ɡɹeɪt lɛŋθ.

"The Elders?" Rand asked patiently. You had to be patient with Loial, with any Ogier. They did not see time the way humans did - who among humans would think of whose turn it was after a thousand years? - and Loial tended to go on at length, given half a chance. Great length.

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz twɪtʃt, ən i ɡeɪv mɪn ənʌðɝ lʊk, ɹəsivd ənʌðɝ ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ smaɪl ɪn ɹɪtɝn. "wɛl, əz aɪ sɛd, aɪ vɪzəɾəd ɔl ðə stɛɾɪŋ bʌt ʃæŋktaɪ. kɑɹldɪn wʊdnt ɡoʊ ɪnsaɪd. hid ɹæðɝ slip ɛvɹi naɪɾ ʌndɝ ə bʊʃ ðən bi kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə sɔɹs fəɹ ə mɪnət." ɹænd dɪd nɑt seɪ ə wɝd, bʌt lɔɪəl ɹeɪzd ɪz hænz fɹəm ɪz niz, pɑmz aʊt. "aɪ æm ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ðə pɔɪnt, ɹænd. aɪ æm. aɪ dɪd wʌɾ aɪ kʊd, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf. ðə stɛɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz toʊl mi tə ɡoʊ hoʊm ən liv mæɾɝz tə oʊldɝ ən waɪzɝ hɛdz. soʊ dɪd ʃædun ən mɑɹdun, ɪn ðə maʊntənz ɑn ðə ʃædoʊ koʊst. ði ʌðɝ slɛɾɪŋ əɡɹid tə ɡɑɹd ðə weɪɡeɪts. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ ɹɪli bɪliv ðɛɹz ɛni deɪnʒɝ, bʌt ðeɪ əɡɹid, soʊ jə noʊ ðəl kip ə kloʊs ɡɑɹd. ən aɪm ʃʊɹ sʌmwʌn wɪl teɪk wɝd tə ʃæŋktaɪ. ði ɛldɝz ɪn ʃæŋktaɪ nɛvɝ laɪk hævɪŋ ə weɪɡeɪt ɹaɪɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ. aɪ mʌst əv hɝɾ ɛldɝ heɪmən seɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. aɪ noʊ ðəl əɡɹi tə hæv ɪt wɑtʃt."

Loial's ears twitched, and he gave Min another look, received another encouraging smile in return. "Well, as I said, I visited all the stedding but Shangtai. Karldin wouldn't go inside. He'd rather sleep every night under a bush than be cut off from the Source for a minute." Rand did not say a word, but Loial raised his hands from his knees, palms out. "I am getting to the point, Rand. I am. I did what I could, but I don't know whether it was enough. The stedding in the Borderlands told me to go home and leave matters to older and wiser heads. So did Shadoon and Mardoon, in the mountains on the Shadow Coast. The other sledding agreed to guard the Waygates. I don't think they really believe there's any danger, but they agreed, so you know they will keep a close guard. And I'm sure someone will take word to Shangtai. The Elders in Shangtai never liked having a Waygate right outside the stedding. I must have heard Elder Haman say a hundred times that it was dangerous. I know they'll agree to have it watched."

ɹænd nɑɾəd sloʊli. oʊɡiɝ nɛvɝ laɪd, əɹ ət lis ðə fju hu meɪd ði ətɛmpt wɝ soʊ pʊɹ əɾ ɪt ðət ðeɪ sɛldəm tʃɹaɪɾ ə sɛkən taɪm. ən oʊɡiɝz wɝd wɑz teɪkən əz sɪɹiəsli əz ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz swɔɹn oʊθ. ðə weɪɡeɪts wəd bi ɡɑɹɾəd kloʊsli. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ən ɪn ðə maʊntənz saʊθ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən tæɹɑbən. fɹəm ɡeɪt tə ɡeɪt, ə mæn kəd dʒɝni fɹəm ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝl tə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ɔl ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ wɝl sʌmhaʊ aʊtsaɪɾ ə taɪm, əɹ meɪbi əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪt. tu deɪz wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə weɪz kəd kæɹi jə ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz, əɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd, dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə pæðz jə tʃoʊz. ən ɪf jə wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə ɹɪsk ðə deɪnʒɝz. jə kəd daɪ vɛɹi izəli ɪn ðə weɪz, əɹ wɝs. ðə weɪz hæd tɝn dɑɹk ən kɝʌptɪd lɔŋ əɡoʊ. tʃɹɑləks dɪd nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt ðæt, ðoʊ, ət lis nɑt wən ðeɪ hæd mɹdʒɹɑl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðɛm.

Rand nodded slowly. Ogier never lied, or at least the few who made the attempt were so poor at it that they seldom tried a second time. An Ogier's word was taken as seriously as anyone else's sworn oath. The Waygates would be guarded closely. Except for those in the Borderlands, and in the mountains south of Amadicia and Tarabon. From gate to gate, a man could journey from the Spine of the World to the Aryth Ocean, from the Borderlands to the Sea of Storms, all in a strange world somehow outside of time, or maybe alongside it. Two days walking along the Ways could carry you a hundred miles, or five hundred, depending on the paths you chose. And if you were willing to risk the dangers. You could die very easily in the Ways, or worse. The Ways had turned dark and corrupted long ago. Trollocs did not care about that, though, at least not when they had Myrddraal driving them.

tʃɹɑləks kɛɹɾ oʊnli fəɹ kɪlɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli wən ðeɪ hæd mɹdʒɹɑl dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðɛm. ən naɪn weɪɡeɪts wəd ɹɪmeɪn ənwɑtʃt, wɪð ðə deɪnʒɝ ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əm maɪɾ oʊpən ʌp tə lɛɾ aʊt tʃɹɑləks baɪ ðə tɛnz ə θaʊzənz. sɛɾɪŋ ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv ɡɑɹd wɪθaʊt ðə stɛɾɪŋ'?, koʊɑpɝeɪʃən maɪt bi ɪmpɑsəbəl. mɛni pipəl dɪd nɑt bɪliv oʊɡiɝ ɪɡzɪstəd, ən fju ʌv ðoʊz u dɪd wɑntəd tə mɛɾəl wɪθaʊt liv. meɪbi ði æʃəmən, ɪf i hæɾ ɪnʌf i kəd tʃɹʌst.

Trollocs cared only for killing, especially when they had Myrddraal driving them. And nine Waygates would remain unwatched, with the danger that any of them might open up to let out Trollocs by the tens of thousands. Setting any sort of guard without the stedding'?, cooperation might be impossible. Many people did not believe Ogier existed, and few of those who did wanted to meddle without leave. Maybe the Asha'man, if he had enough he could trust.

sʌɾənli, hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u wɑz taɪɝd. lɔɪəl lʊkt wɔɹn ən ɡɔnt.

Suddenly, he realized that he was not the only one who was tired. Loial looked worn and gaunt.

hɪz koʊt wɑz ɹʌmpəld ən hʌŋ lusli ɑn hɪm. ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ tə bi aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ tu lɔŋ, ən lɔɪəl hæd lɛft ɪz hoʊm ə ɡʊd faɪv jɪɹz əɡoʊ. meɪbi ðoʊz bɹif vɪzəts oʊvɝ ðə læs fju mʌnθs hæd nɑt bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ hɪm. "meɪbi jə ʃəd ɡoʊ hoʊm naʊ, lɔɪəl. stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ɪz ə oʊnli ə fju deɪz fɹəm hɪɹ."

His coat was rumpled and hung loosely on him. It was dangerous for an Ogier to be outside the stedding too long, and Loial had left his home a good five years ago.
