Maybe those brief visits over the last few months had not been enough for him. "Maybe you should go home now, Loial. Stedding Shangtai is a only a few days from here."

lɔɪəlz tʃɛɹ kɹikt əlɑɹmɪŋli əz i sæt boʊlt əpɹaɪt. hɪz ɪɹz ə ʃɑɾ əpɹaɪt, tu, ɪn əlɑɹm.

Loial's chair creaked alarmingly as he sat bolt upright. His ears A shot upright, too, in alarm.

"maɪ mʌðɝ wɪl bi ðɛɹ, ɹænd. ʃiz ə feɪməs spikɝ. ʃi wəd nɛvɝ mɪs ə ɡɹeɪt stʌmp." "ʃi kæn əv kʌm ɔl ðə weɪ bæk fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɔlɹɛɾi," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. lɔɪəlz mʌðɝ wɑz səpoʊzədli ə feɪməs wɔkɝ, tu, jɛt ðəɹ wɝ lɪməts, ivən fəɹ oʊɡiɝ. "ju doʊnt noʊ maɪ mʌðɝ," lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd, ə dʒɹʌm bumɪŋ dɑɹkli. "ʃil stɪl əv ɛɹɪθ ɪn toʊ, tu. ʃi wɪl." mɪn lin təwɔɹd ði oʊɡiɝ, ə deɪnʒɝəs laɪɾ ɪn əɹ aɪz. "ðə weɪ jə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɛɹɪθ, aɪ noʊ jə wɑnə mɛɹi hɝ, soʊ waɪ dʒju kip ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm hɝ?"

"My mother will be there, Rand. She's a famous Speaker. She would never miss a Great Stump." "She can't have come all the way back from the Two Rivers already," Rand told him. Loial's mother was supposedly a famous walker, too, yet there were limits, even for Ogier. "You don't know my mother," Loial muttered, a drum booming darkly. "She'll still have Erith in tow, too. She will." Min leaned toward the Ogier, a dangerous light in her eyes. "The way you talk about Erith, I know you want to marry her, so why do you keep running from her?"

ɹænd stʌɾid əɹ fɹəm ðə faɪɝpleɪs. mɛɹɪdʒ. eɪvinhə əsum ðəɾ i wəd mɛɹi hɝ, ən ɪleɪn ən mɪn əz wɛl, ɪn ði il fæʃən. ɪleɪn əpɪɹd tə θɪŋk soʊ, tu, stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ðət simd. hi θɔt ʃi dɪd. wʌd mɪn θɪŋk? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sɛd. hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛɾ əm bɑn hɪm. ðə bɑnd wəd smʌðɝ əm ɪn ɡɹif wən i daɪd.

Rand studied her from the fireplace. Marriage. Aviendha assumed that he would marry her, and Elayne and Min as well, in the Aiel fashion. Elayne appeared to think so, too, strange as that seemed. He thought she did. What did Min think? She had never said. He should never have let them bond him. The bond would smother them in grief when he died.

lɔɪəlz ɪɹz tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð kɑʃən, naʊ. ðoʊz ɪɹz wɝ wʌn ɹizən oʊɡiɝ meɪd pʊɹ laɪɝz. hi meɪd pleɪkeɪɾɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝz əz ðoʊ mɪn wɝ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ə ðɛm. "wɛl, aɪ də wɑn tə, mɪn. ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ du. ɛɹɪθ ɪz bjuɾəfəl, ən vɛɹi pɝsɛptɪv. dɪɾ aɪ ɛvɝ tɛl jə haʊ kɛɹfəli ʃi lɪsən tə mi ɪkspleɪn əbaʊt . . . ? ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ dɪd. aɪ tɛl ɛvɹibɑɾi aɪ mit. aɪ də wɑnə mɛɹi hɝ. bʌt nɑt jɛt. ɪɾ ɪzən laɪk wɪð jə hjumənz, mɪn. jə də ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹænd æsks. ɛɹɪθ wɪl ɪkspɛk mi tə sɛɾəl daʊn ən steɪ hoʊm.

Loial's ears trembled with caution, now. Those ears were one reason Ogier made poor liars. He made placating gestures as though Min were the larger of them. "Well, I do want to, Min. Of course, I do. Erith is beautiful, and very perceptive. Did I ever tell you how carefully she listened to me explain about . . . ? Of course, I did. I tell everybody I meet. I do want to marry her. But not yet. It isn't like with you humans, Min. You do everything Rand asks. Erith will expect me to settle down and stay home.

waɪvz nɛvɝ lɛɾ ə hʌzbənd ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ əɹ də ɛniθɪŋ, ɪf ɪt minz livɪŋ ðə stɛɾɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə fju deɪz. aɪ hæv maɪ bʊk tə fɪnɪʃ, ən haʊ kən aɪ də ðəɾ ɪf aɪ doʊn si ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹænd dʌz? aɪm ʃʊɹ hiz dʌn ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz sɪns aɪ lɛf kɛɹhin, ən aɪ noʊ əl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɪɾ ɔl daʊn ɹaɪt. ɛɹɪθ dʒʌst wʊdn ʌndɝstænd. mɪn? mɪn, ɑɹ jə æŋɡɹi wɪð mi?"

Wives never let a husband go anywhere or do anything, if it means leaving the stedding for more than a few days. I have my book to finish, and how can I do that if I don't see everything Rand does? I'm sure he's done all sorts of things since I left Cairhien, and I know I'll never get it all down right. Erith just wouldn't understand. Min? Min, are you angry with me?"

"wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk aɪm æŋɡɹi?" ʃi sɛd kuli. lɔɪəl saɪd hɛvəli, ən soʊ klɪɹli ɪn ɹɪlif ðət ɹænd ɔlmoʊst stɛɹd. laɪt, ði oʊɡiɝ æktʃəli  θɔt ʃi mɛnt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ æŋɡɹi! ɹænd nu hi wɑz filɪŋ ɪz weɪ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wən ɪt keɪm tə wɪmən, ivən mɪn - meɪbi ɪspɛʃli mɪn - bʌt lɔɪəl hæd bɛɾɝ lɝn ə lɑt mɔɹ ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi nu bɪfɔɹ i mɛɹiɾ ɪz ɛɹɪθ. ʌðɝwaɪz, ʃi wəd skɪn ɪm aʊt laɪk ə sɪk ɡoʊt. bɛs tə ɡɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum bɪfɔɹ mɪn dɪɾ ɛɹɪθs dʒɑb fəɹ hɝ. ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt.

"What makes you think I'm angry?" she said coolly. Loial sighed heavily, and so clearly in relief that Rand almost stared. Light, the Ogier actually thought she meant she was not angry! Rand knew he was feeling his way in the dark when it came to women, even Min - maybe especially Min - but Loial had better learn a lot more than he already knew before he married his Erith. Otherwise, she would skin him out like a sick goat. Best to get him out of the room before Min did Erith's job for her. Rand cleared his throat.

"θɪŋk ɑn ɪɾ oʊvɝnaɪt, lɔɪəl," hi sɛd. "meɪbi jəl tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪn baɪ mɔɹnɪŋ." pɑɹɾ ə hɪm hoʊp lɔɪəl wʊd. ði oʊɡiɝ hæd bɪn tu lɔŋ fɹəm hoʊm. ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɪm, ðoʊ. . . . hi kəd juz lɔɪəl, ɪf wʌɾ əliviə hæd toʊld ɪm əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn wɑz tʃɹu. səmtaɪmz, hi dɪsɡʌstəd hɪmsɛlf. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ nid tə tɔk tə bæʃɪɹ, naʊ. ən lɑɡən." hɪz maʊθ taɪɾənd ɝaʊn ðə neɪm. wʌt wɑz lɑɡən duɪŋ ɪn æʃəmən blæk?

"Think on it overnight, Loial," he said. "Maybe you'll change your mind by morning." Part of him hoped Loial would. The Ogier had been too long from home. Another part of him, though. . . . He could use Loial, if what Alivia had told him about the Seanchan was true. Sometimes, he disgusted himself. "In any case, I need to talk to Bashere, now. And Logain." His mouth tightened around the name. What was Logain doing in Asha'man black?

lɔɪəl dɪd nɑt stænd. ɪndid, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən ɡɹu mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəld, ɪɹz slæntɪŋ bæk ən aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹupɪŋ. "ɹænd, ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ nid tə tɛl ju. əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hu keɪm wɪð ʌs." laɪtnɪŋz flɛɹɾ ənu aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊz əz i wɛn ɑn, ən ðə θʌndɝ kɹæʃt oʊvɝhɛd hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. wɪð səm stɔɹmz, ə lʌl oʊnli mɛn ðə wɝst wɑz kʌmɪŋ.

Loial did not stand. Indeed, his expression grew more troubled, ears slanting back and eyebrows drooping. "Rand, there's something I need to tell you. About the Aes Sedai who came with us." Lightnings flared anew outside the windows as he went on, and the thunder crashed overhead harder than ever. With some storms, a lull only meant the worst was coming.

aɪ toʊl jə tə kɪl əm ɔl wən jə hæd ðə tʃæns, luz θɝɪn læft. aɪ toʊl ju.

I told you to kill them all when you had the chance, Lews Therin laughed. I told you.

"ɑɹ jə pɑzəɾɪv ðeɪv bɪn bɑndəd, sæmɪtsu?" kædzueɪn æsk fɝmli. ən laʊdli ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə θʌndɝ bumɪŋ ɑn ðə mænɝ haʊsəz ɹuftɑp. θʌndɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ fɪɾ əɹ mud.

"Are you positive they've been bonded, Samitsu?" Cadsuane asked firmly. And loudly enough to be heard over the thunder booming on the manor house's rooftop. Thunder and lightning fit her mood.

ʃi wʊɾə laɪk tə snɑɹl. ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə ɡʊdli mɛʒɝ ə hɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən ɪkspɪɹiəns tə sɪt kɑmli ən sɪp hɑt dʒɪnʒɝ ti. ʃi hæd nɑt lɛɾ ɪmoʊʃən ɡɛt ði ʌpɝ hæn ɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə baɪt sʌmθɪŋ. əɹ sʌmwʌn.

She would have liked to snarl. It required a goodly measure of her training and experience to sit calmly and sip hot ginger tea. She had not let emotion get the upper hand in a very long time, but she wanted to bite something. Or someone.

sæmɪtsu hɛld ə pɔɹsələn kʌp ə ti, tu, bʌt ʃi hæd jɛt tə swɑloʊ ə dʒɹɑp, ən ʃi hæɾ ɪɡnɔɹd kædzueɪnz ɔfɝ ʌv ə tʃɛɹ. ðə slɛndɝ sɪstɝ tɝn fɹəm piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz ə ðə lɛfθæn faɪɝpleɪs, ðə bɛlz ɪn əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ dʒɪŋɡəlɪŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ʃi hæd nɑt bɑðɝd tə dʒɹaɪ hɝ hɛɹ pɹɑpɝli, ən ɪt hʌŋ dæmp ən hɛvi daʊn əɹ bæk. hɝ heɪzəl aɪz wɝ ənizi. "ɪts hɑɹdli ðə sɔɹɾ ə kwɛstʃən aɪ kəɾ æsk ə sɪstɝ, naʊ ɪz ɪt, kædzueɪn, ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli dɪdn tɛl mi. əz u wʊd? ət fɝst, aɪ θɔt meɪbi ðeɪ hæd dʌn laɪk mɛɹaɪs ən kɔɹəl. ən pʊɹ deɪdʒiən." ə bɹif wɪns ə sɪmpəθi kɹɔst əɹ feɪs. ʃi nu ɪn fʊl ðə peɪn ðət wɑz nɔɪŋ ət deɪdʒiən oʊvɝ əɹ lɔs. ɛni sɪstɝ bɪɑn əɹ fɝst wɔɹɾɝ nu ðət tu wɛl. "bʌɾ ɪts pleɪn tʌvaɪn ən ɡɑbɹɛl ɑɹ boʊθ wɪð lɑɡən. aɪ θɪŋk ɡɑbɹɛl ɪz bɛɾɪŋ hɪm. ɪf ðɛɹz bɑndɪŋ bɪn dʌn, ɪt wɑz ðə mɛn u dɪɾ ɪt."

Samitsu held a porcelain cup of tea, too, but she had yet to swallow a drop, and she had ignored Cadsuane's offer of a chair. The slender sister turned from peering into the flames of the lefthand fireplace, the bells in her dark hair jingling as she shook her head. She had not bothered to dry her hair properly, and it hung damp and heavy down her back. Her hazel eyes were uneasy. "It's hardly the sort of question I could ask a sister, now is it, Cadsuane, and they certainly didn't tell me. As who would? At first, I thought maybe they had done like Merise and Corele. And poor Daigian." A brief wince of sympathy crossed her face. She knew in full the pain that was gnawing at Daigian over her loss. Any sister beyond her first Warder knew that too well. "But it's plain Toveine and Gabrelle are both with Logain. I think Gabrelle is bedding him. If there's bonding been done, it was the men who did it."

"tɝnəbaʊt," kædzueɪn mʌɾɝd ɪndə hɝ ti. səm sɛd ðət tɝnəbaʊt wɑz fɛɹ pleɪ, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪlivd ɪn faɪɾɪŋ fɛɹ. iðɝ jə fɔt, əɹ jə dɪd nɑt, ən ɪt wɑz nɛvɝ ə ɡeɪm. fɛɹnəs wɑz fəɹ pipəl stændɪŋ seɪfli tə wʌn saɪd, tɔkɪŋ waɪl ʌðɝz blɛd. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ʃi kəd də bɪɑn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə weɪ tə bæləns ɪvɛns. bæləns wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə seɪm əz fɛɹnəs. wʌɾ ə dɔɡz dɪnɝ ðɪs wɑz tɝnɪŋ ɪntu. "aɪm ɡlæd jə ɡeɪv mi ət list ə lɪɾəl wɔɹnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ hæv tə feɪs tʌvaɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, bʌɾ aɪ wɑn jə tə ɹɪtɝn tə kɛɹhin ðə fɝs θɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ."

"Turnabout," Cadsuane muttered into her tea. Some said that turnabout was fair play, but she had never believed in fighting fair. Either you fought, or you did not, and it was never a game. Fairness was for people standing safely to one side, talking while others bled. Unfortunately, there was little she could do beyond trying to find a way to balance events. Balance was not at all the same as fairness. What a dog's dinner this was turning into. "I'm glad you gave me at least a little warning before I have to face Toveine and the others, but I want you to return to Cairhien the first thing tomorrow."

"ðɛɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ aɪ kəd du, kædzueɪn," sæmɪtsu sɛd bɪɾɝli. "hæf ðə pipəl aɪ ɡeɪv ən ɔɹɾɝ hæd bɪɡʌn tʃɛkɪŋ wɪð sæʃəl tə si ɪf ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf toʊl mi tə maɪ feɪs ʃiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sɛd dɪfɹənt. lɔɹd bæʃɪɹ tɔkt əɹ ɪndə tɝnɪŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝz lus - aɪ hæv noʊ aɪdiə haʊ hi faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊɾ əm ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs - ən ʃi tɔk sɔɹɪliə ɪndə ɪt, ən ðəɹ wɑzn ðə lis θɪŋ aɪ kəd də tə stɑp ɪt. sɔɹɪliə wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ əz ɪf aɪ hæd dʒʌst æbdəkeɪɾəd! ʃi dʌzn ʌndɝstænd, ən ʃi meɪɾ ɪt pleɪn ʃi θɪŋks ɪm ə ful. ðɛɹz noʊ pɔɪn əɾ ɔl ɪn mi ɡoʊɪŋ bæk, ənlɛs jə ɪkspɛk mi tə kæɹi sæʃəlz ɡlʌvz fəɹ hɝ."

"There was nothing I could do, Cadsuane," Samitsu said bitterly. "Half the people I gave an order had begun checking with Sashalle to see if it was right, and the other half told me to my face she'd already said different. Lord Bashere talked her into turning the Warders loose - I have no idea how he found out about them in the first place - and she talked Sorilea into it, and there wasn't the least thing I could do to stop it. Sorilea was behaving as if I had just abdicated! She doesn't understand, and she made it plain she thinks I'm a fool. There's no point at all in me going back, unless you expect me to carry Sashalle's gloves for her."

"aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə wɑtʃ hɝ, sæmɪtsu. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌt wʌn ə ðiz dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn sɪstɝz dʌz wən niðɝ aɪ nɔɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən hoʊldɪŋ ə swɪtʃ. juv ɔlweɪz bɪn vɛɹi əbzɝvənt." peɪʃəns wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz əɹ stʃɹɔŋɡəs tʃɹeɪt, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd wɪð sæmɪtsu. ðə jɛloʊ wɑz əbzɝvənt, ən ɪntɛlədʒənt, ən stʃɹɔnwɪl moʊst ə ðə taɪm, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə bɛst əlaɪv ət hilɪŋ ət list əntɪl ði əpɪɹəns ə dɑɹnɝ flɪn -  bʌt ʃi kəd sʌfɝ ðə moʊst əstɑnɪʃɪŋ kəlæpsɪz ɪn əɹ kɑnfəɾəns. ðə stɪk nɛvɝ wɝkt wɪð sæmɪtsu, bʌt pæts ɑn ðə bæk dɪd, ən ɪt wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs nɑt tə juz wʌt wɝkt. əz kædzueɪn ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ haʊ ɪntɛlədʒənt ʃi wɑz, haʊ skɪld ət hilɪŋ - ðət wɑz ɔlweɪz nɛsəsɛɹi, wɪð sæmɪtsu; ʃi kəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ə dɪpɹɛʃən oʊvɝ feɪlɪŋ tə hil ə dɛd mæn - haʊ klɛvɝ, ði ɝæfɛlɪn sɪstɝ bɪɡæn tə dʒɹɔ ʌp əɹ kəmpoʊʒɝ. ən əɹ sɛlf-əʃʊɹəns.

"I expect you to watch her, Samitsu. No more than that. I want to know what one of these Dragonsworn sisters does when neither I nor the Wise Ones are looking over their shoulders and holding a switch. You've always been very observant." Patience was not always her strongest trait, but sometimes it was required with Samitsu. The Yellow was observant, and intelligent, and strongwilled most of the time, not to mention the best alive at Healing at least until the appearance of Darner Flinn -  but she could suffer the most astonishing collapses in her confidence. The stick never worked with Samitsu, but pats on the back did, and it was ridiculous not to use what worked. As Cadsuane reminded her how intelligent she was, how skilled at Healing - that was always necessary, with Samitsu; she could go into a depression over failing to Heal a dead man - how clever, the Arafellin sister began to draw up her composure. And her self-assurance.

"ju kən bi əʃʊɹd sæʃəl woʊn tʃeɪnʒ əɹ stɑkɪŋz wɪθaʊɾ aɪ noʊ ɪt," ʃi sɛd kɹɪspli. ɪn tʃɹuθ, kædzueɪn ɪkspɛktəd noʊ lɛs. "bʌɾ ɪf jə doʊn maɪn mi æskɪŋ," wɪð əɹ kɑnfəɾəns ɹɪstɔɹd, sæmɪtsuz toʊn meɪd ðət ðə mɛɹəs kɝɾəsi; ʃi wɑz noʊ ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ flaʊɝ ɪksɛpt wən əɹ sɛlfəʃʊɹəns wikənd, "waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, ət ðə bæk ɛn ə tiɹ? wʌts jʌŋ ælθɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du? əɹ ʃəɾ aɪ seɪ, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə gɑnə hæv ɪm du?" "hi ɪntɛnz sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi deɪnʒɝəs," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊz, ʃɑɹp sɪlvɝ fɔɹks ɪn ə skaɪ nɪɹ əz dɑɹk əz naɪt. ʃi nu ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd. ʃi dʒʌs dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə stɑp ɪt.

"You can be assured Sashalle won't change her stockings without I know it," she said crisply. In truth, Cadsuane expected no less. "But if you don't mind me asking," with her confidence restored, Samitsu's tone made that the merest courtesy; she was no shrinking flower except when her selfassurance weakened, "why are you here, at the back end of Tear? What's young al'Thor going to do? Or should I say, what are you going to have him do?" "He intends something very dangerous," Cadsuane replied. Lightning flashed outside the windows, sharp silver forks in a sky near as dark as night. She knew exactly what he intended. She just did not know whether to stop it.

"ɪɾ əz tə ɛnd!" ɹænd θʌndɝd, ɛkoʊd baɪ ðə kɹæʃɪz ɪn ðə skaɪ. hi hæd dɑft ɪz koʊt bɪfɔɹ ðɪs ɪntɝvju, ən ɹoʊld ʌp ɪz ʃɝtslivz tə bɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡənz twaɪn ɝaʊn ɪz fɹɑɹmz ɪn skɑɹləɾ ən ɡoʊld, ðə ɡoʊldən-meɪn hɛdz ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz. hi wɑntəd ðə mæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɹimaɪndəd wɪð ɛvɹi lʊk ðəɾ i wɑz feɪsɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. bʌɾ ɪz hænz wɝ fɪsts, tə kip ɪm fɹəm ɡɪvɪŋ ɪn tə luz θɝɪnz ɝdʒɪŋz ən θɹɑɾəlɪŋ blʌɾi lɑɡən əblɝ. "aɪ doʊnt niɾ ə wɔɹ wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən jə blʌɾi æʃəmən blʌɾi wɛl woʊnt ɡɪmi ə wɔɹ wɪð ðə waɪt taʊɝ!

"It has to end!" Rand thundered, echoed by the crashes in the sky. He had doffed his coat before this interview, and rolled up his shirtsleeves to bare the Dragons twined around his forearms in scarlet and gold, the golden-maned heads resting on the backs of his hands. He wanted the man in front of him reminded with every look that he was facing the Dragon Reborn. But his hands were fists, to keep him from giving in to Lews Therin's urgings and throttling bloody Logain Ablar. "I don't need a war with the White Tower, and you bloody Asha'man bloody well won't give me a war with the White Tower!

də aɪ meɪk maɪsɛlf ʌndɝstʊd?" lɑɡən, hænz ɹɛstɪŋ izəli ətɑp ðə lɔŋ hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ. hi wɑz ə bɪɡ mæn, ɪf smɔlɝ ðən ɹænd, wɪð ə stɛɾi ɡeɪz ðət ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðəɾ i hæd bɪn dʒɹɛs daʊn əɹ kɔl tə əkaʊnt. ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ən ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊl dʒɹæɡən ɡlɪɾɝd bɹaɪtli ɪn ðə læmplaɪɾ ɑn ðə haɪ kɑlɝ ə hɪz blæk koʊt, ən ðəɾ ɪtsɛlf lʊk fɹɛʃli aɪɝnd. "ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ ɹilis ðɛm?" hi æskt kɑmli. "wɪl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹilis ðoʊz ʌv aʊɝz ðeɪv teɪkən?"

Do I make myself understood?" Logain, hands resting easily atop the long hilt of his sword, did not flinch. He was a big man, if smaller than Rand, with a steady gaze that gave no sign that he had been dressed down or called to account. The silver sword and red-and-gold Dragon glittered brightly in the lamplight on the high collar of his black coat, and that itself looked freshly ironed. "Are you saying release them?" he asked calmly. "Will the Aes Sedai release those of ours they've taken?"

"noʊ!" ɹænd sɛd kɝtli. ən saʊɝli. "wʌts dʌn kæn bi əndʌn." mɛɹaɪs hæd bɪn soʊ ʃɑkt wən i sədʒɛstəd ʃi ɹilis nɛɹɪʃmə, jə wʊɾə θɔɾ i wɑz æskɪŋ əɹ tə əbændən ə pʌpi baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd. ən i səspɛktəd flɪn wəd faɪɾ əz hɑɹd tə hæŋ ɑn tə kɔɹəl əz ʃi tə hɪm; hi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ bɪtwin ðoʊz tu ðən ðə bɑnd, naʊ. wɛl, ɪf ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd bɑn ə mæn u tʃænəld, wʌt wɑz tə seɪ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən kəd nɑt fɪks ɑn ə ɡɝnpi oʊl mæn? "ju ɹilaɪz ðə mɛs juv kɹieɪɾəd, ðoʊ, doʊn ju? əz ɪɾ ɪz, ði oʊnli mæn u kən tʃænəl ðəɾ ɪleɪɾə wɑns əlaɪv ɪz mi, ən ðəɾ oʊnli tɪl ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz dʌn. wʌns ʃi lɝnz ə ðɪs, ʃɪl bi twaɪs əz hɑt tə si jə ɔl dɛɾ ɛni weɪ ʃi kən mænədʒ ɪt. aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ ði ʌðɝ lɑt wɪl ɹiækt, bʌɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ɔlweɪz ə ʃɑɹp bɑɹɡɪnɝ. aɪ meɪ hæv tə tɛl ɔf æʃəmən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə bɑn əntɪl ðeɪv əz mɛni ʌv jə əz jə də ʌv ðɛm. ðæts ɪf ðeɪ doʊn dʒʌs dɪsaɪd jə ɔl əv tə daɪ əz sun əz ðeɪ kən ɝeɪnʒ ɪt, tu. wʌts dʌn ɪz dʌn, bʌt ðəɹ kænɑt bi ɛni mɔɹ!" lɑɡən stɪfən ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ wɪð ɛvɹi wɝd, bʌɾ ɪz ɡeɪz hɛld ɑn ɹænz. ɪt wɑz pleɪn əz hɔɹnz ɑn ə ɹæm ðəɾ i wɑz ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. mɪn hæd wɑntəd noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs miɾɪŋ ən teɪkən hɝsɛlf ɔf tə ɹid; ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk ʌp fɹəm daʊn ɪn hɹɪd pɛlz bʊks, bʌt ʃi faʊn əm fæsəneɪɾɪŋ.

"No!" Rand said curtly. And sourly. "What's done can't be undone." Merise had been so shocked when he suggested she release Narishma, you would have thought he was asking her to abandon a puppy by the side of the road. And he suspected Flinn would fight as hard to hang on to Corele as she to him; he was fairly certain there was more between those two than the bond, now. Well, if an Aes Sedai could bond a man who channeled, what was to say a pretty woman could not fix on a girnpy old man? "You realize the mess you've created, though, don't you? As it is, the only man who can channel that Elaida wants alive is me, and that only till the Last Battle is done. Once she learns of this, she'll be twice as hot to see you all dead any way she can manage it. I don't know how the other lot will react, but Egwene was always a sharp bargainer. I may have to tell off Asha'man for Aes Sedai to bond until they have as many of you as you do of them. That's if they don't just decide you all have to die as soon as they can arrange it, too. What's done is done, but there cannot be any more!" Logain stiffened a little more with every word, but his gaze held on Rand's. It was plain as horns on a ram that he was ignoring the others in the sitting room. Min had wanted no part of this meeting and taken herself off to read; Rand could not make up from down in Herid Pel's books, but she found them fascinating.

hi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəd lɔɪəl ɹɪmeɪn, ðoʊ, ən ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə stʌɾi ðə fleɪmz ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs.

He had insisted Loial remain, though, and the Ogier was pretending to study the flames in the fireplace.

ɪksɛpt wən i ɡlænst ət ðə dɔɹ, tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ, əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i kəd slɪp aʊɾ ənnoʊɾɪst ʌndɝ kʌvɝ ə ðə stɔɹm. dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ əpɪɹɾ ivən ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən i ɹɪli wɑz əlɔŋsaɪd ði oʊɡiɝ, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ mæn wɪð dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz, ə bik ʌv ə noʊz, ən θɪk mʌstæʃɪz kɝvɪŋ daʊn ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ. hi hæd wɔɹn ɪz sɔɹd, tu, ə ʃɔɹɾɝ bleɪd ðən lɑɡənz, ən sɝpəntaɪn. bæʃɪɹ spɛn mɔɹ taɪm piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz waɪnkʌp ðən lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ɪz aɪz tʌtʃt lɑɡən, hi ʌnkɑnʃəsli ɹæn ə θʌm əlɔŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ʌnkɑnʃəs. "teɪm ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ," lɑɡən sɛd, koʊldli ənkʌmftəɹbəl ɪkspleɪnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ən ɑɾiəns. sʌɾən laɪtnɪŋ kloʊs tə ðə haʊs kæst ɪz feɪs ɪn lʊɹəd ʃædoʊz fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ə blik mæsk ə dɑɹknəs. "aɪ əsumd ɪt keɪm fɹəm ju." hɪz aɪz muv slaɪtli ɪn bæʃɪɹz dɝɛkʃən, ən ɪz maʊθ taɪɾənd.

Except when he glanced at the door, tufted ears twitching, as if wondering whether he could slip out unnoticed under cover of the storm. Davram Bashere appeared even shorter than he really was alongside the Ogier, a graying man with dark tilted eyes, a beak of a nose, and thick mustaches curving down around his mouth. He had worn his sword, too, a shorter blade than Logain's, and serpentine. Bashere spent more time peering into his winecup than looking at anything else, but whenever his eyes touched Logain, he unconsciously ran a thumb along his sword hilt. Rand thought it was unconscious. "Taim gave the order," Logain said, coldly uncomfortable explaining himself in front of an audience. Sudden lightning close to the house cast his face in lurid shadows for an instant, a bleak mask of darkness. "I assumed it came from you." His eyes moved slightly in Bashere's direction, and his mouth tightened.

"teɪm dʌz ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz pipəl θɪŋk ɑɹ ət jəɹ dɝɛkʃən," hi wɛn ɑn ɹɪlʌktənli, "bʌt hiz ɪz oʊn plænz. flɪn ən nɛɹɪʃmə ən mænfɝ ɑɹ ɑn ðə dɛzɝɾɝz' lɪst, laɪk ɛvɹi æʃəmən jə kɛpt wɪð ju. ən hiz ə koʊɾɝi ʌv twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi hi kips kloʊs ən tʃɹeɪnz pɹaɪvətli. ɛvɹi mæn u wɛɹz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz wʌn ə ðət ɡɹup ɪksɛp mi, ən hiɾ əv kɛp ðə dʒɹæɡən fɹəm mi, ɪf i dɛɹd.

"Taim does a great many things people think are at your direction," he went on reluctantly, "but he has his own plans. Flinn and Narishma and Manfor are on the deserters' list, like every Asha'man you kept with you. And he has a coterie of twenty or thirty he keeps close and trains privately. Every man who wears the Dragon is one of that group except me, and he'd have kept the Dragon from me, if he dared.

noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt juv dʌn, ɪts taɪm tə tɝn jəɹ aɪz tə ðə blæk taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ teɪm splɪts ɪt wɝs ðən ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪz. ɪf i dʌz, jəl faɪn ðə lɑɹdʒɝ pɑɹɾ ɪz lɔɪəl tə hɪm, nɑt ju. ðeɪ noʊ hɪm.

No matter what you've done, it is time to turn your eyes to the Black Tower before Taim splits it worse than the White Tower is. If he does, you'll find the larger part is loyal to him, not you. They know him.

moʊst əv nɛvɝ ivən sin ju." ɪɹɪɾəbli, ɹænd pʊʃt ɪz slivz daʊn ən dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ.

Most have never even seen you." Irritably, Rand pushed his sleeves down and dropped into a chair.

wʌɾ i hæd dʌn meɪd noʊ mæɾɝ tə lɑɡən. ðə mæn nu seɪɾɪn wɑz klin, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bɪliv ɹænd əɹ ɛni mæn hæɾ æktʃəli  dʌn ðə klɛnzɪŋ. dɪɾ i θɪŋk ðə kɹieɪɾɝ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɾ ə mɝsɪfəl hæn æftɝ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ə sʌfɝɪŋ? ðə kɹieɪɾɝ hæd meɪd ðə wɝld ən ðən lɛf hjumənkaɪn tə meɪk ʌv ɪt wʌt ðeɪ wʊd, ə hɛvən əɹ ðə pɪɾ ə dum baɪ ðɛɹ tʃuzɪŋ. ðə kɹieɪɾɝ hæd meɪd mɛni wɝlz, wɑtʃt itʃ flaʊɝ əɹ daɪ, ən ɡɔn ɑn tə meɪk ɛnləs wɝlz bɪɑnd. ə ɡɑɹɾənɝ dɪd nɑt wip fəɹ itʃ blɑsəm ðət fɛl.

What he had done made no matter to Logain. The man knew saidin was clean, but he could not believe Rand or any man had actually done the cleansing. Did he think the Creator had decided to stretch out a merciful hand after three thousand years of suffering? The Creator had made the world and then left humankind to make of it what they would, a heaven or the Pit of Doom by their choosing. The Creator had made many worlds, watched each flower or die, and gone on to make endless worlds beyond. A gardener did not weep for each blossom that fell.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hi θɔt ðoʊz mʌst əv bɪn luz θɝɪnz ɹɪflɛkʃənz. hi hæd nɛvɝ ɡɔn ɑn ðət weɪ əbaʊt ðə kɹieɪɾɝ əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðəɾ i ɹɪkɔld. bʌɾ i kəd fil luz θɝɪn nɑɾɪŋ ɪn əpɹuvəl, ə mæn lɪsnɪŋ tə sʌmwʌn ɛls. stɪl, ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə kaɪndə θɪŋ i wʊɾə kənsɪɾɝd bɪfɔɹ luz θɝɪn. haʊ mʌtʃ speɪs ɹɪmeɪn bɪtwin ðɛm?

For an instant, he thought those must have been Lews Therin's reflections. He had never gone on that way about the Creator or anything else that he recalled. But he could feel Lews Therin nodding in approval, a man listening to someone else. Still, it was not the kind of thing he would have considered before Lews Therin. How much space remained between them?

"teɪm wɪl əv tə weɪt," hi sɛd wɛɹəli. haʊ lɔŋ kəd teɪm weɪt? hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz nɑt tə hɪɹ luz θɝɪn ɹeɪdʒɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə kɪl ðə mæn. hi wɪʃt ðət meɪɾ ɪm fil iziɝ. "dɪd jə dʒʌs kʌm tə si ðət lɑɡən ɹitʃt mi seɪfli, bæʃɪɹ, əɹ tə tɛl mi sʌmbɑɾi stæb dɑbɹeɪn? əɹ juv ən ɝdʒən tæsk fəɹ mi, tu?"

"Taim will have to wait," he said wearily. How long could Taim wait? He was surprised not to hear Lews Therin raging for him to kill the man. He wished that made him feel easier. "Did you just come to see that Logain reached me safely, Bashere, or to tell me somebody stabbed Dobraine? Or do you have an urgent task for me, too?"

bæʃɪɹ ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ɹændz toʊn, ən ɪz dʒɔ taɪɾənd əz i ɡlænst ət lɑɡən, bʌɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi snɔɹɾɪd soʊ hɑɹɾ ɪz θɪk mʌstæʃɪz ʃəɾ əv ʃeɪkən. "tu mɛn ɹænsæk maɪ tɛnt," hi sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ɪz waɪnkʌp daʊn ɑn ə kɑɹv blu teɪbəl əɡɛns ðə wɔl, "wʌn kæɹiɪŋ ə noʊɾ aɪ kəd swɛɹ aɪ ɹoʊt maɪsɛlf ɪf aɪ dɪdnt noʊ bɛɾɝ. ən ɔɹɾɝ tə kæɹi əweɪ 'sɝɾən aɪɾəmz.' lɔɪəl tɛlz mi ðə fɛloʊz u naɪfɛd dɑbɹeɪn hæd ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ə noʊt, əpɛɹənli ɪn dɑbɹeɪnz hænd. ə blaɪn mæn kəd si wʌt ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ, wɪð ə lɪɾəl θɔt. dɑbɹeɪn ən aɪ ɑɹ ðə moʊs laɪkli kændəɾeɪts tə bi ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə silz fəɹ ju. juv θɹi, ən jə seɪ θɹi ɑɹ bɹoʊkən. meɪbi ðə ʃædoʊ noʊz wɛɹ ðə læst ɪz."

Bashere raised an eyebrow at Rand's tone, and his jaw tightened as he glanced at Logain, but after a moment, he snorted so hard his thick mustaches should have shaken. "Two men ransacked my tent," he said, setting his winecup down on a carved blue table against the wall, "one carrying a note I could swear I wrote myself if I didn't know better. An order to carry away 'certain items.' Loial tells me the fellows who knifed Dobraine had the same sort of note, apparently in Dobraine's hand. A blind man could see what they were after, with a little thought. Dobraine and I are the most likely candidates to be guarding the seals for you. You have three, and you say three are broken. Maybe the Shadow knows where the last is."

lɔɪəl hæd tɝn fɹəm ðə faɪɝpleɪs əz ðə sɑldəiən spoʊk, hɪz ɪɹz ɹɪdʒəd, ən naʊ hi bɝst aʊt, "ðæɾ ɪz sɪɹiəs, ɹænd. ɪf sʌmwʌn bɹeɪks ɔl ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, əɹ meɪbi ivən dʒʌst wʌn əɹ tu mɔɹ, ðə dɑɹk wʌn kəd bɹeɪk fɹi. ivən jə kæn feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn! aɪ min, aɪ noʊ ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ jə wɪl, bʌt ðəɾ əz tə bi dʒʌst ə weɪ ʌv spikɪŋ." ivən lɑɡən lʊkt kənsɝnd, hɪz aɪz stʌɾiɪŋ ɹænd əz ɪf mɛʒɝɪŋ ɪm əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Loial had turned from the fireplace as the Saldaean spoke, his ears rigid, and now he burst out, "That is serious, Rand. If someone breaks all the seals on the Dark One's prison, or maybe even just one or two more, the Dark One could break free. Even you can't face the Dark One! I mean, I know the Prophecies say you will, but that has to be just a way of speaking." Even Logain looked concerned, his eyes studying Rand as if measuring him against the Dark One.

ɹænd lin bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛɾ ɪz taɪɹədnəs ʃoʊ. ðə silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən ɑn wʌn hænd, teɪm splɪɾɪŋ ði æʃəmən ɑn ði ʌðɝ. wɑz ðə sɛvənθ sil ɔlɹɛɾi bɹoʊkən?

Rand leaned back in his chair, careful not to let his tiredness show. The seals on the Dark One's prison on one hand, Taim splitting the Asha'man on the other. Was the seventh seal already broken?

wɑz ðə ʃædoʊ bɪɡɪnɪŋ ði oʊpənɪŋ muvz ə ðə læs bæɾəl? "ju toʊl mi sʌmθɪŋ wʌns, bæʃɪɹ. ɪf jəɹ ɛnəmi ɔfɝz jə tu tɑɹɡəts. . . . "

Was the Shadow beginning the opening moves of the Last Battle? "You told me something once, Bashere. If your enemy offers you two targets. . . . "

"stʃɹaɪk əɾ ə θɝd," bæʃɪɹ fɪnɪʃt pɹɑmpli, ən ɹænd nɑɾəd. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsaɪɾɪd, ɛniweɪ. θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ðə wɪndoʊz tɪl ðə keɪsməns ʃʊk. ðə stɔɹm wɑz stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ. "aɪ kæn faɪt ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə sintʃæn ət ðə seɪm taɪm. aɪm sɛndɪŋ ðə θɹi ʌv jə tə ɝeɪnʒ ə tʃɹus wɪð ðə sintʃæn." bæʃɪɹ ən lɑɡən sim stʌn ɪndə saɪləns. əntɪl ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə ɑɹɡju, wʌn ɑn tɑp ə ði ʌðɝ. lɔɪəl dʒʌs lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə feɪnt.

"Strike at a third," Bashere finished promptly, and Rand nodded. He had already decided, anyway. Thunder rattled the windows till the casements shook. The storm was strengthening. "I can't fight the Shadow and the Seanchan at the same time. I am sending the three of you to arrange a truce with the Seanchan." Bashere and Logain seemed stunned into silence. Until they began to argue, one on top of the other. Loial just looked ready to faint.

ɛlzə fɪdʒəɾɪd, lɪsnɪŋ tə fɝəl ɹipɔɹt wʌt hæɾ əkɝd sɪns ʃi lɛft ɪm ɪn kɛɹhin. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə mænz hɑɹʃ vɔɪs ðəɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd hɝ. ʃi heɪɾəd laɪtnɪŋ, ən wɪʃt ʃi kəd wɔɹɾ əweɪ ðə vaɪələn laɪts flæʃɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz əz ʃi hæd wɔɹɾɪd əɹ ɹum əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. noʊ wʌn wəd θɪŋk əɹ wɪʃ fəɹ pɹaɪvəsi stʃɹeɪnʒ, sɪns ʃi hæd spɛn twɛnti jɪɹz kənvɪnsɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ðət ʃi wɑz mɛɹid tə ðə peɪl-hɛɹd mæn. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs, fɝəl lʊk ðə sɔɹɾ ə wʊmən wəd mɛɹi, tɔl ən lin ən kwaɪt pɹɪɾi. ðə hɑɹɾ ɛdʒ tə hɪz maʊθ oʊnli meɪɾ ɪz feɪs mɔɹ soʊ, ɹɪli. ʌv kɔɹs, səm maɪt θɪŋk ɪt pəkjuljɝ ðət ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hæd mɔɹ ðən wʌn wɔɹɾɝ əɾ ə taɪm, ɪf ðeɪ stɑp tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt. ə mæn wɪð dʒʌs ðə ɹaɪt kwɑləfəkeɪʃənz wɑz dɪfəkəl tə faɪnd, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi ʃəd stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ. laɪtnɪŋ lɪɾ ʌp ðə wɪndoʊz əɡɛn.

Elza fidgeted, listening to Fearil report what had occurred since she left him in Cairhien. It was not the man's harsh voice that irritated her. She hated lightning, and wished she could ward away the violent lights flashing in the windows as she had warded her room against eavesdropping. No one would think her wish for privacy strange, since she had spent twenty years convincing everyone that she was married to the pale-haired man. Despite his voice, Fearil looked the sort a woman would marry, tall and lean and quite pretty. The hard edge to his mouth only made his face more so, really. Of course, some might think it peculiar that she had never had more than one Warder at a time, if they stopped to think about it. A man with just the right qualifications was difficult to find, but perhaps she should start looking. Lightning lit up the windows again.

"jɛs, jɛs, ɪnʌf," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn faɪnəli. "ju dɪd ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ, fɝəl. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn teɪkən əz ɑɾ ɪf jə wɝ ði oʊnli wʌn tə ɹəfjuz tə faɪn jəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ə sɛns ə ɹɪlif flæʃt θɹu ðə bɑnd. ʃi wɑz stʃɹɪkt əbaʊɾ oʊbiɾiəns tə hɝ ɔɹɾɝz, ən waɪl i nu ʃi kəd nɑt kɪl ɪm -  wəd nɑt, ət list - pʌnɪʃmən oʊnli ɹikwaɪɝɾ əɹ tə mæsk ðə bɑn soʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ ɪz peɪn. ðæt, ən ə wɔɹd tə mʌfəl ɪz skɹimz. ʃi dɪslaɪk skɹimɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi dɪslaɪk laɪtnɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz dʒʌst əz wɛl jəɹ wɪð mi," ʃi wɛn ɑn. ə pɪɾi ðət ði il sævədʒəz wɝ stɪl hoʊldɪŋ fɛɹə, ðoʊ ʃi wəɾ əv tə kwɪz ðə waɪɾ ɑn ɪɡzækli waɪ ʃi hæd swɔɹn bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bi tʃɹʌstɪd. əntɪl ðə dʒɝni tə kɛɹhin, ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn ʃi ʃɛɹɾ ɛniθɪŋ wɪð fɛɹə. ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪt pɪɾi ðət nʌn ə hɝ oʊn hɑɹt wɑz wɪð hɝ, bʌɾ oʊnli ʃi hæd bɪn sɛn tə kɛɹhin, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt kwɛstʃən ði ɔɹɾɝz ʃi ɹəsivd ɛni mɔɹ ðən fɝəl kwɛstʃən ðoʊz ʃi ɡeɪv. "aɪ θɪŋk ə fju pipəl ɑɹ gɑnə hæv tə daɪ sun." əz sun əz ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd wɪtʃ wʌnz. fɝəl baʊɾ ɪz hɛd, ən ə dʒoʊlt ə plɛʒɝ keɪm θɹu ðə bɑnd. hi dɪd laɪk kɪlɪŋ. "ɪn ðə minwaɪl, jəl kɪl ɛniwʌn u θɹɛɾənz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

"Yes, yes, enough," she broke in finally. "You did the right thing, Fearil. It would have been taken as odd if you were the only one to refuse to find your Aes Sedai." A sense of relief flashed through the bond. She was strict about obedience to her orders, and while he knew she could not kill him -  would not, at least - punishment only required her to mask the bond so she did not share his pain. That, and a ward to muffle his screams. She disliked screaming almost as much as she disliked lightning. "It is just as well you're with me," she went on. A pity that the Aiel savages were still holding Fera, though she would have to quiz the White on exactly why she had sworn before she could be trusted. Until the journey to Cairhien, she had not known she shared anything with Fera. A very great pity that none of her own heart was with her, but only she had been sent to Cairhien, and she did not question the orders she received any more than Fearil questioned those she gave. "I think a few people are going to have to die soon." As soon as she decided which ones. Fearil bowed his head, and a jolt of pleasure came through the bond. He did like killing. "In the meanwhile, you will kill anyone who threatens the Dragon Reborn.

ɛniwʌn." æftɝ ɔl, ɪt hæd bɪkʌm pɝfəkli klɪɹ tə hɝ, waɪl ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ə kæptɪv ə ðə sævədʒəz.

Anyone." After all, it had become perfectly clear to her, while she herself was a captive of the savages.

ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd tə ɹitʃ tɑɹmən ɡdən, əɹ haʊ kəd ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd dɪfiɾ ɪm ðɛɹ?

The Dragon Reborn had to reach Tarmon Gai'don, or how could the Great Lord defeat him there?

tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv

CHAPTER 25

wən tə wɛɹ dʒuəlz pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli ʌp ən daʊn ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpəts ðət flɔɹd ðə tɛnt, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ wɪð dɪskʌmfɝɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɡɹin sɪlk koʊɾ i hæd sɛldəm wɔɹn sɪns feɪl hæd hæɾ ɪt meɪd. ʃi sɛd ði ɪlæbɹət sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi suɾəd ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt ðə waɪd lɛðɝ bɛl səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɪz æks əɾ ɪz saɪd, ðə wʌn əz pleɪn əz ði ʌðɝ, oʊnli pɔɪntəɾ ʌp ðəɾ i wɑz ə ful pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi mɔɹ ðən i wɑz.

When to Wear Jewels Perrin strode impatiently up and down the flowered carpets that floored the tent, shrugging with discomfort in the dark green silk coat he had seldom worn since Faile had had it made. She said the elaborate silver embroidery suited his shoulders, but the wide leather belt supporting his axe at his side, the one as plain as the other, only pointed up that he was a fool pretending to be more than he was.

səmtaɪmz i tʌɡd ɪz ɡɔnləts taɪɾɝ, əɹ ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk, laɪɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ ɹɛɾi fəɹ ɪm tə pʊɾ ɑn. twaɪs, hi pʊld ə ʃiɾ ə peɪpɝ fɹəm ɪz sliv ən ənfoʊldəɾ ɪt tə stʌɾi ðə skɛtʃt mæp ə meɪɾən waɪl i peɪst. ðət wɑz ðə taʊn wɛɹ feɪl wɑz biɪŋ hɛld. dʒɑndɪn ən ɡɛɾ ən hu hæd kɑɾ ʌp tə ðə fliɪŋ ɪnhæbəɾənts ə meɪɾən, bʌt ði oʊnli jusfəl θɪŋ ðeɪ hæd ɡɑɾən wɑz ðɪs mæp, ən meɪkɪŋ ɛniwʌn pɔz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pɹəvaɪd ðət hæd bɪn ə tʃɔɹ. ðoʊz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə faɪt wɝ dɛɾ əɹ wɛɹɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn waɪt fəɹ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ; ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪn tə fli wɝ ði oʊld ən ðə vɛɹi jʌŋ, ðə sɪk ən ðə leɪm. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə dʒɑndɪn, ðə θɔt ðət sʌmwʌn maɪt fɔɹs əm tə ɹɪtɝn ən faɪt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd kwɪkən ðɛɹ stɛps nɔɹθ təwɔɹɾ ændɝ ən seɪfti. ðə mæp wɑz ə pʌzəl, wɪð ɪts meɪz ə stʃɹits ən ðə leɪɾiz fɔɹtʃɹəs ən ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪstɝn ɪn ðə nɔɹθis kɔɹnɝ. ɪt tæntəlaɪzd ɪm wɪð pɑsəbɪləɾiz. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz oʊnli ɪf i faʊn ə səluʃən tə ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pʌzəl ðət wɑz nɑt ʃoʊn ɑn ðə mæp, ðə hjudʒ mæs ə ʃeɪɾoʊ sɝaʊndɪŋ ðə wɔl taʊn, nɑt tə mɛnʃən fɔɹ əɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd ʃeɪɾoʊ waɪz wʌnz u kəd tʃænəl. soʊ ðə mæp wɛn bæk ɪndə hɪz sliv, ən i kəntɪnjud tə peɪs. ðə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp tɛn ɪtsɛlf meɪɾ ɪm tʃeɪf əz mʌtʃ əz ðə mæp, ən soʊ dɪd ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz, ðə ɡɪlt-ɛdʒ tʃɛɹz ðət foʊldəd fəɹ stɔɹədʒ ən ðə moʊzeɪɪk-tɑp teɪbəl ðət dɪd nɑt, ðə stænd-mɪɹɝ ən ðə mɪɹɝd wɑʃstæn ən ivən ðə bɹæs-baʊn tʃɛsts stændɪŋ ɪn ə ɹoʊ əlɔŋ ən aʊɾɝ wɔl. ɪt wɑz bɛɹli laɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən ɔl twɛlv ə ðə læmps wɝ lɪt, mɪɹɝz spɑɹklɪŋ.

Sometimes he tugged his gauntlets tighter, or glared at his fur-lined cloak, lying across the back of a chair ready for him to put on. Twice, he pulled a sheet of paper from his sleeve and unfolded it to study the sketched map of Maiden while he paced. That was the town where Faile was being held. Jondyn and Get and Hu had caught up to the fleeing inhabitants of Maiden, but the only useful thing they had gotten was this map, and making anyone pause long enough to provide that had been a chore. Those strong enough to fight were dead or wearing gai'shain white for the Shaido; those who remained to flee were the old and the very young, the sick and the lame. According to Jondyn, the thought that someone might force them to return and fight the Shaido had quickened their steps north toward Andor and safety. The map was a puzzle, with its maze of streets and the lady's fortress and the great cistern in the northeast corner. It tantalized him with possibilities. But they were possibilities only if he found a solution to the greater puzzle that was not shown on the map, the huge mass of Shaido surrounding the walled town, not to mention four or five hundred Shaido Wise Ones who could channel. So the map went back into his sleeve, and he continued to pace. The red-striped tent itself made him chafe as much as the map, and so did the furnishings, the gilt-edged chairs that folded for storage and the mosaic-topped table that did not, the stand-mirror and the mirrored washstand and even the brass-bound chests standing in a row along an outer wall. It was barely light outside, and all twelve of the lamps were lit, mirrors sparkling.

ðə bɹeɪʒɝz ðət hæd hɛld ɔf ðə naɪts fɹizɪŋ koʊl stɪl kənteɪn ə fju ɛmbɝz. hi hæɾ ivən hæd feɪlz tu sɪlk hæŋʒɪŋz, wɝkt wɪð laɪnz ə bɝdz ən flaʊɝz, bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ən hʌŋ fɹəm ðə ɹuf poʊlz. hi hæd lɛt læmɡwɪn tʃɹɪm ɪz bɪɹɾ ən ʃeɪv ɪz tʃiks ən nɛk; hi hæd wɑʃt ən dɑn klin kloʊðz. hi hæd hæd ðə tɛn sɛɾ ʌp əz ɪf feɪl wɝ gɑnə ɹɪtɝn ɛni moʊmən fɹəm ə ɹaɪd. ɔl soʊ ɛvɹiwʌn wəd lʊk əɾ ɪm ən si ə blʌɾi lɔɹd, lʊk əɾ ɪm ən fil kɑnfəɾənt. ən ɛvɹi bɪɾ ʌv ɪt ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ðət feɪl wɑz nɑɾ aʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ. tʌɡɪŋ ɔf wʌn ə hɪz ɡɔnləts, hi fɛlt ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən ɹæn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ ðə ɹɔhaɪd kɔɹd tʌkt ɪn ðɛɹ. θɝɾi-tu nɑts, naʊ. hi dɪd nɑt nid ɹimaɪndɪŋ ə ðæt, bʌt səmtaɪmz i leɪ əweɪk ə hoʊl naɪɾ ɪn ðə bɛɾɪŋ ðət dɪd nɑɾ əv feɪl ɪn ɪt, kaʊntɪŋ ðoʊz nɑts. sʌmhaʊ, ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm ə kənɛkʃən tə hɝ. ɛniweɪ, weɪkfəlnəs wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən naɪtmɛɹz.

The braziers that had held off the night's freezing cold still contained a few embers. He had even had Faile's two silk hangings, worked with lines of birds and flowers, brought out and hung from the roof poles. He had let Lamgwin trim his beard and shave his cheeks and neck; he had washed and donned clean clothes. He had had the tent set up as if Faile were going to return any moment from a ride. All so everyone would look at him and see a bloody lord, look at him and feel confident. And every bit of it reminded him that Faile was not out riding. Tugging off one of his gauntlets, he felt in his coat pocket and ran his fingers along the rawhide cord tucked in there. Thirty-two knots, now. He did not need reminding of that, but sometimes he lay awake a whole night in the bedding that did not have Faile in it, counting those knots. Somehow, they had become a connection to her. Anyway, wakefulness was better than nightmares.

"ɪf jə doʊn sɪt daʊn, jə ɑɹ gɑnə bi tu taɪɝd tə ɹaɪd tə soʊ hæbɝ ivən wɪð nilz hɛlp," bɹəleɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ feɪnli əmjuzd. "dʒʌst wɑtʃɪŋ jə ɪz ɪɡzɔstɪŋ mi." hi mænədʒ nɑt tə ɡlɛɹ ət hɝ. ɪn ə dɑɹk blu sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs, ə waɪd ɡoʊldən nɛkləs stʌɾɪd wɪð faɪɝdʒɹɑps taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ən ðə nɛɹoʊ kɹaʊn ə min hoʊldɪŋ ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪɾ əbʌv əɹ bɹaʊz, ðə fɝst ə min wɑz siɾəd ətɑp əɹ kɹɪmzən kloʊk ɑn wʌn ə ðə foʊldɪŋ tʃɛɹz wɪð əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ ɝaʊn ɹɛd ɡlʌvz ɪn əɹ læp. ʃi lʊkt əz kəmpoʊzd əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ʃi smɛld . . . peɪʃənt. hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi hæd stɑp smɛlɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ ə fæt læm kɑɾ ɪn bɹæmbəlz fəɹ əɹ mil, bʌɾ i ɔlmoʊs fɛlt ɡɹeɪtfəl tə hɝ. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə hæv sʌmwʌn i kəd tɔk tə əbaʊt mɪsɪŋ feɪl. ʃi lɪsənd, ən smɛld ə sɪmpəθi.

"If you don't sit down, you are going to be too tired to ride to So Habor even with Neald's help," Berelain said, sounding faintly amused. "Just watching you is exhausting me." He managed not to glare at her. In a dark blue silk riding dress, a wide golden necklace studded with firedrops tight around her neck and the narrow crown of Mayene holding a golden hawk in flight above her brows, the First of Mayene was seated atop her crimson cloak on one of the folding chairs with her hands folded around red gloves in her lap. She looked as composed as an Aes Sedai, and she smelled . . . patient. He did not understand why she had stopped smelling as if he were a fat lamb caught in brambles for her meal, but he almost felt grateful to her. It was good to have someone he could talk to about missing Faile. She listened, and smelled of sympathy.

"aɪ wɑnə bi hɪɹ ɪf. . . wən ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz bɹɪŋ ɪn səm pɹɪznɝz." ðə slɪp meɪɾ ɪm ɡɹɪmɑs əz mʌtʃ əz ðə dɪleɪ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i daʊɾɪd. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðeɪ wəd kæptʃɝ səm ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, jɛɾ əpɛɹənli ðət wɑz noʊ izi mæɾɝ. teɪkɪŋ pɹɪznɝz dɪd noʊ ɡʊɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ kəd bi bɹɔɾ əweɪ, ən ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ oʊnli kɛɹləs kəmpɛɹd tə ʌðɝ il. səlɪn hæd bɪn peɪʃənt, tu, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ ɪt tə hɪm. ɪt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd fəɹ ɪm tə bi peɪʃənt, ðoʊ. "wʌts kipɪŋ ɑɹɡændə?" hi ɡɹaʊld. əz ɪf ðə ɡildænɪnz neɪm hæd sʌmən ɪm ət læst, ɑɹɡændə pʊʃt θɹu ði ɛntʃɹi flæps, hɪz feɪs laɪk stoʊn ən ɪz aɪz sʌŋkən. hi lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi slɛpt əz lɪɾəl əz pɛɹɪn. ðə ʃɔɹt mæn wɔɹ ɪz sɪlvɝi bɹɛstpleɪt, bʌt noʊ hɛlmət. hi hæd nɑt ʃeɪv jɛt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ɡɹeɪɪŋ stʌbəl ɡɹɪzəld ɪz tʃɪn. dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ɡɔntələɾəd hænd, ə fæt lɛðɝ pɝs klɪŋkt əz i sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl əlɔŋsaɪd tu ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. "fɹʌm ðə kwinz stʃɹɔŋbɑks," hi sɛd saʊɝli. hi hæd sɛd lɪɾəl ðə læs tɛn deɪz ðət wɑz nɑt saʊɝ. "ɪnʌf tə kʌvɝ əɹ ʃɛɹ ən mɔɹ. aɪ hæd tə bɹeɪk oʊpən ðə lɑk ən pʊt θɹi mɛn tə ɡɑɹd ðə tʃɛst. ɪts ə tɛmteɪʃən tə ðə bɛst ə ðɛm, wɪð ðə lɑk bɹoʊkən." "ɡʊd, ɡʊd," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə saʊn tu ɪmpeɪʃənt. hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wɛðɝ ɑɹɡændə hæd tə sɛɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz kwinz stʃɹɔŋbɑks. hɪz oʊn pɝs wɑz ðə smɔləst ə ðə θɹi, ən i hæd ɡlin ɛvɹi bɪɾ ʌv ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ i kəd faɪn tə meɪk ɪɾ ʌp. slɪŋɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hi pɪkt ʌp ðə pɝsɪz ən bɹʌʃt pæs ðə mæn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ. tə hɪz dɪsɡʌst, ðə kæmp hæd teɪkən ə mɔɹ pɝmənən ɛɹ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt baɪ dɪzaɪn, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də əbaʊɾ ɪt.

"I want to be here if. . . when Gaul and the Maidens bring in some prisoners." The slip made him grimace as much as the delay. It was as if he doubted. Sooner or later they would capture some of the Shaido, yet apparently that was no easy matter. Taking prisoners did no good unless they could be brought away, and the Shaido were only careless compared to other Aiel. Sulin had been patient, too, explaining it to him. It was getting so hard for him to be patient, though. "What's keeping Arganda?" he growled. As if the Ghealdanin's name had summoned him at last, Arganda pushed through the entry flaps, his face like stone and his eyes sunken. He looked as though he slept as little as Perrin. The short man wore his silvery breastplate, but no helmet. He had not shaved yet this morning, and graying stubble grizzled his chin. Dangling from one gauntleted hand, a fat leather purse clinked as he set it on the table alongside two already there. "From the Queen's strongbox," he said sourly. He had said little the last ten days that was not sour. "Enough to cover our share and more. I had to break open the lock and put three men to guard the chest. It's a temptation to the best of them, with the lock broken." "Good, good," Perrin said, trying not to sound too impatient. He did not care whether Arganda had to set a hundred men guarding his queen's strongbox. His own purse was the smallest of the three, and he had gleaned every bit of gold or silver he could find to make it up. Slinging his cloak around his shoulders, he picked up the purses and brushed past the man out into the gray morning. To his disgust, the camp had taken a more permanent air, though it was not by design, and there was nothing he could do about it.

mɛni ʌv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn slɛpt ʌndɝ tɛns naʊ, peɪl bɹaʊn pætʃt kænvəs ɹæðɝ ðən stʃɹaɪpt ɹɛd laɪk hɪz, bʌt bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ eɪɾ əɹ tɛn mɛn itʃ, wɪð ðɛɹ ɪl-əsɔɹɾɪd pɑlɹmz stækt ət ðə fɹʌnt, ən ði ʌðɝz hæd tɝn ðɛɹ tɛmpɝɛɹi bɹʌʃ ʃɛltɝz ɪndə stɝɾi lɪɾəl hʌts ʌv woʊvən ɛvɝɡɹin bɹæntʃəz. ðə tɛns ən hʌts meɪɾ ət bɛs miændɝɪŋ ɹoʊz, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk ðə ɹɪdʒəd laɪnz sin əmʌŋ ðə ɡildænɪn ən minɝz, jɛɾ ɪt stɪl lʊkt ə lɪɾəl laɪk ə vɪlədʒ, wɪð pæðz ən leɪnz θɹu ðə snoʊ tʃɹæmpəl daʊn tə bɛɹ, fɹoʊzən ɝθ. ə nit stoʊn faɪɝ-ɹɪŋ sɝaʊndəɾ itʃ ə ðə kʊkfaɪɝz, wɛɹ klʌstɝz ə mɛn stʊd kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd əɡɛns ðə koʊld, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ bɹɛkfəst. ɪt wɑz wʌt wɑz ɪn ðoʊz blæk aɪɝn kʊkpɑts ðət hæd pɛɹɪn muvɪŋ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. wɪð soʊ mɛni mɛn hʌntɪŋ, ɡeɪm wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ θɪn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ aʊt. ðeɪ wɝ daʊn tə sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ skwɝəlz' hɔɹdz ʌv eɪkɔɹnz tə ɡɹaɪn fəɹ stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ði oʊtmil, ən ðɪs leɪɾ ɪn ðə wɪntɝ, wʌt ðeɪ faʊnd wɝ oʊld ən dʒɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ət bɛst. ðə saʊɝ mɪkstʃɝ fɪl ðə bɛli æftɝ ə fæʃən, bʌt jə hæd tə bi hʌŋɡɹi tə ɡɛɾ ɪt daʊn. moʊst ə ðə feɪsəz pɛɹɪn kəd si wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kʊkpɑts iɡɝli. ðə læst ə ðə kɑɹts wɝ ɹætlɪŋ ðoʊ ə ɡæp meɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪŋ ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks ɝaʊn ðə kæmp, ðə kɛɹhinɪn dʒɹaɪvɝz swɑð tə ðɛɹ ɪɹz ən hʌntʃt ɑn ðɛɹ sits laɪk dɑɹk sæks ʌv wʊl. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə kɑɹts hæd hɛld wɑz stækt ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə kæmp. ɛmpti, ðeɪ lɝtʃt ɪn ðə ɹʌts lɛf baɪ ðə kɑɹts əhɛd, ə sɪŋɡəl faɪl dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ fɔɹəst. pɛɹɪnz əpɪɹəns wɪð bɹəleɪn ən ɑɹɡændə əɾ ɪz hilz kɑzd ə stɝ, ɔlðoʊ nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðə hʌŋɡɹi tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. oʊ, ə fju meɪd kɔʃəs nɑdz ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən - wʌn əɹ tu fulz ɡeɪv ɹʌf baʊz! - bʌt moʊst stɪl tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk əɾ ɪm wən bɹəleɪn wɑz ɪn ðə vəsɪnəɾi. ɪɾiəts. stoʊn-bɹeɪn ɪɾiəts! ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ʌðɝ pipəl, ðoʊ, ɡæðɝɾ ə lɪɾəl weɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp tɛnt, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə leɪnz bɪtwin ði ʌðɝ tɛns.

Many of the Two Rivers men slept under tents now, pale brown patched canvas rather than striped red like his, but big enough for eight or ten men each, with their ill-assorted polearms stacked at the front, and the others had turned their temporary brush shelters into sturdy little huts of woven evergreen branches. The tents and huts made at best meandering rows, not at all like the rigid lines seen among the Ghealdanin and Mayeners, yet it still looked a little like a village, with paths and lanes through the snow trampled down to bare, frozen earth. A neat stone fire-ring surrounded each of the cookfires, where clusters of men stood cloaked and hooded against the cold, waiting for their breakfast. It was what was in those black iron cookpots that had Perrin moving this morning. With so many men hunting, game was growing thin on the ground, and everything else was running out. They were down to searching for squirrels' hoards of acorns to grind for stretching the oatmeal, and this late in the winter, what they found were old and dried out at best. The sour mixture filled the belly after a fashion, but you had to be hungry to get it down. Most of the faces Perrin could see were watching the cookpots eagerly. The last of the carts were rattling though a gap made in the ring of sharpened stakes around the camp, the Cairhienin drivers swathed to their ears and hunched on their seats like dark sacks of wool. Everything the carts had held was stacked in the center of the camp. Empty, they lurched in the ruts left by the carts ahead, a single file disappearing into the surrounding forest. Perrin's appearance with Berelain and Arganda at his heels caused a stir, although not among the hungry Two Rivers men. Oh, a few made cautious nods in his direction - one or two fools gave rough bows! - but most still tried not to look at him when Berelain was in the vicinity. Idiots. Stone-brained idiots! There were plenty of other people, though, gathered a little way from the red-striped tent, crowding into the lanes between the other tents.

ən ənɑɹmɝd minɝ soʊlʒɝ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ koʊt keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð bɹəleɪnz waɪt mɛɹ, boʊɪŋ ən bɛndɪŋ tə hoʊld əɹ stɝəp.

An unarmored Mayener soldier in a gray coat came running with Berelain's white mare, bowing and bending to hold her stirrup.

ənʊɹə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ʌp ɑn ə slik mɛɹ ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz bɹəleɪnz maʊnt wɑz peɪl. θɪn biɾɪd bɹeɪdz hæŋɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃɛs fɹəm ðə kaʊl ə hɝ kloʊk, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɛɹli sim tə noʊɾəs ðə wʊmən ʃi wɑz səpoʊz tə ædvaɪz. bæk stɪf, ʃi pɪɹd fɪksədli təwɔɹd ðə loʊ il tɛns, wɛɹ nʌθɪŋ muv bʌt ðə θɪn weɪvɝɪŋ laɪnz ə smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə smoʊk hoʊlz. wʌn aɪd ɡælɛn, ɪn ɪz ɹɛd hɛlməɾ ən bɹɛstpleɪɾ ən aɪpætʃ, meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ðə tæɹɑbənɝ sɪstɝz ɪnətɛntʃən, ðoʊ. əz sun əz bɹəleɪn əpɪɹd, hi bɑɹkt ən ɔɹɾɝ ðət stɪfən fɪfti ʌv ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz tə stætʃuz, lɔŋ, ɹɛd-stʃɹimɝd stil-tɪp lænsɪz əpɹaɪɾ ət ðɛɹ saɪdz, ən wən ʃi maʊntəd, ɡælɛn snæpt ənʌðɝ kəmæn ðət pʊɾ əm ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz soʊ smuðli ðeɪ sim tə muv əz wʌn.

Annoura was already up on a sleek mare almost as dark as Berelain's mount was pale. Thin beaded braids hanging down her chest from the cowl of her cloak, the Aes Sedai barely seemed to notice the woman she was supposed to advise. Back stiff, she peered fixedly toward the low Aiel tents, where nothing moved but the thin wavering lines of smoke rising from the smoke holes. One eyed Gallenne, in his red helmet and breastplate and eyepatch, made up for the Taraboner sister's inattention, though. As soon as Berelain appeared, he barked an order that stiffened fifty of the Winged Guards to statues, long, red-streamered steel-tipped lances upright at their sides, and when she mounted, Gallenne snapped another command that put them on their horses so smoothly they seemed to move as one.

ɑɹɡændə dɝɛktəɾ ə fɹaʊn təwɔɹd ði il tɛns, fɹaʊn ət ðə minɝz, ðən stɔkt oʊvɝ tə wɛɹ əz mɛni ɡildænɪn lænsɝz weɪɾəd, ɪn ʃaɪnɪŋ ɑɹmɝ ən kɑnɪkəl ɡɹin hɛlməts, ən spoʊk sɔfli tə ðə fɛloʊ hu wəd bi kəmændɪŋ ðɛm, ə lin mæn neɪm kaɪɹən u pɛɹɪn səspɛktəd wɑz nɑbli bɔɹn fɹəm ðə hɔɾi ɡeɪz vɪzəbəl bɪhaɪn ðə feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz sɪlvɝd hɛlmət. ɑɹɡændə wɑz ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf ðət kaɪɹən hæd tə bɛn tə lɪsən tə wʌɾ i hæd tə seɪ, ən ðə nəsɛsəɾi fɹɔstəd ðə tɔlɝ mænz feɪs ivən mɔɹ. wʌn ə ðə mɛn bɪhaɪn kaɪɹən wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ə stæf wɪð ə ɹɛd bænɝ bɛɹɪŋ ðə θɹi sɪks-pɔɪntəd sɪlvɝ stɑɹz ʌv ɡildən ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə ɡɹin-stʃɹimɝd læns, ən wʌn ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz kæɹid minz ɡoʊldən hɔk ɑn blu. ɛɹæm wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, ðoʊ ɔf tə wʌn saɪɾ ən nɑt ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪd. ɹæpt ɪn ɪz pjutʃɹɪd ɡɹin kloʊk, sɔɹd hɪlt ɹaɪzɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hi ʃɛɹɾ ɪz dʒɛləs skaʊlz bɪtwin ðə minɝz ən ðə ɡildænɪn. wən i sɔ pɛɹɪn, ðə mænz skaʊl tɝn sʌlən, ən i hɝiɾ ɔf, blʌndɝɪŋ θɹu ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ bɹɛkfəst. hi dɪd nɑt pɔz tə ɔfɝ əpɑlədʒiz wən i bʌmp sʌmwʌn. ɛɹæm hæd ɡɹoʊn ɪnkɹisɪŋli tʌtʃi, snæpɪŋ ən snɪɹɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt pɛɹɪn əz ðə deɪz pæst ən ðeɪ sæɾ ən weɪɾəd. jɛstɝdeɪ, hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs kʌm tə bloʊz wɪð ə pɛɹ ʌv ɡildænɪn oʊvɝ sʌmθɪŋ nʌn ə ðɛm kəd kwaɪt ɹikɔl wʌns ðeɪ wɝ sɛpɝeɪɾəd, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛɹæm sɛd ðə ɡildænɪn hæd noʊ ɹɪspɛkt ən ðeɪ sɛɾ i hæɾ ə bæd maʊθ. ðət wɑz waɪ ðə fɔɹmɝ tɪŋkɝ wɑz steɪɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. θɪŋz wɝ laɪkli tə bi tʌtʃi ɪnʌf ɪn soʊ hæbɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛɹæm stɑɹɾɪŋ ə faɪt wən pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ. "kip ən aɪ ɑn ɛɹæm," hi sɛd kwaɪətli wən dænɪl bɹɔɾ ʌp ɪz beɪ. "æn kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ɑɹɡændə," hi æɾəd, stʌfɪŋ ðə pɝsɪz ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən bʌklɪŋ ðə flæps daʊn taɪt. ðə weɪɾ ə bɹəleɪnz kɑntʃɹəbjuʃən bælənst ɪz ən ɑɹɡændəz təɡɛðɝ vɛɹi naɪsli. wɛl, ʃi hæd kɑz tə bi dʒɛnɝəs. hɝ mɛn wɝ əz hʌŋɡɹi əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. "ɑɹɡændə lʊks ə mæn ɹɛɾi tə də sʌmθɪŋ stupəd, tə mi." steɪɝ fɹɪskt ə lɪɾəl ən tɔst ɪz hɛɾ əz pɛɹɪn tʊk ðə ɹeɪnz, bʌt ðə stæljən sɛɾəld kwɪkli ʌndɝ ə fɝm, dʒɛntəl hænd.

Arganda directed a frown toward the Aiel tents, frowned at the Mayeners, then stalked over to where as many Ghealdanin lancers waited, in shining armor and conical green helmets, and spoke softly to the fellow who would be commanding them, a lean man named Kireyin who Perrin suspected was nobly born from the haughty gaze visible behind the face-bars of his silvered helmet. Arganda was short enough that Kireyin had to bend to listen to what he had to say, and the necessity frosted the taller man's face even more. One of the men behind Kireyin was carrying a staff with a red banner bearing the three six-pointed Silver Stars of Ghealdan instead of a green-streamered lance, and one of the Winged Guards carried Mayene's Golden Hawk on blue. Aram was there, too, though off to one side and not ready to ride. Wrapped in his putrid green cloak, sword hilt rising behind his shoulder, he shared his jealous scowls between the Mayeners and the Ghealdanin. When he saw Perrin, the man's scowl turned sullen, and he hurried off, blundering through the Two Rivers men waiting for their breakfast. He did not pause to offer apologies when he bumped someone. Aram had grown increasingly touchy, snapping and sneering at everyone but Perrin as the days passed and they sat and waited. Yesterday, he had almost come to blows with a pair of Ghealdanin over something none of them could quite recall once they were separated, except that Aram said the Ghealdanin had no respect and they said he had a bad mouth. That was why the former Tinker was staying behind this morning. Things were likely to be touchy enough in So Habor without Aram starting a fight when Perrin was not looking. "Keep an eye on Aram," he said quietly when Dannil brought up his bay. "And keep a close eye on Arganda," he added, stuffing the purses into his saddlebags and buckling the flaps down tight. The weight of Berelain's contribution balanced his and Arganda's together very nicely. Well, she had cause to be generous. Her men were as hungry as anyone else. "Arganda looks a man ready to do something stupid, to me." Stayer frisked a little and tossed his head as Perrin took the reins, but the stallion settled quickly under a firm, gentle hand.

dænɪl ɹʌbd ɪz tʌsk-laɪk mʌstæʃɪz wɪð ə koʊld-ɹɛɾənd nʌkəl ən aɪɾ ɑɹɡændə saɪdweɪz, ðən ɛksheɪl hɛvəli ɪn ə mɪst. "aɪl wɑtʃ hɪm, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," hi mʌɾɝd, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ə hɪtʃ, "bʌt noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt jə sɛɾ əbaʊt mi biɪŋ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, əz sun əz jəɹ aʊɾ ə saɪt, hi woʊn lɪsən tə ə θɪŋ aɪ seɪ." ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ðət wɑz tʃɹu. pɛɹɪn wəd ɹæðɝ əv teɪkən ɑɹɡændə wɪð ɪm ən lɛft ɡælɛn hɪɹ, bʌt niðɝ hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛp ðæt. ðə ɡildænɪn dɪɾ æksɛp ðət mɛn ən hɔɹsəz wəd bɪɡɪn stɑɹvɪŋ sun ənlɛs fuɾ ən fɑɾɝ wɝ faʊn sʌmwɛɹ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf spɛn ə deɪ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ɪz kwin ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz. ɪn səm weɪz, hi simd ivən mɔɹ fɹæntɪk ðən pɛɹɪn, əɹ meɪbi dʒʌs mɔɹ ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv ɪn tə ɪt. lɛf tə hɪmsɛlf, ɑɹɡændə wʊɾə bɪn ɛdʒɪŋ ə lɪɾəl nɪɹɝ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɛvɹi deɪ əntɪl i wɑz ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɹɛɾi tə daɪ tə fɹi feɪl. ɑɹɡændə dʒʌst simd ɹɛɾi tə daɪ. "du wʌt jə kən tə kip ɪm fɹəm duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ stupəd, dænɪl." æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hi æɾəd, "æz lɔŋ əz ɪt dʌzn kʌm tə bloʊz." ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli soʊ fɑɹ i kəɾ ɪkspɛk dænɪl tə ɹistʃɹeɪn ðə fɛloʊ, æftɝ ɔl. ðəɹ wɝ θɹi ɡildænɪn fəɹ ɛvɹi tu ɹɪvɝz mæn, ən feɪl wəd nɛvɝ bi fɹiɾ ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðɛm kɪlɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ. pɛɹɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn steɪɝz flæŋk. laɪt, bʌɾ i wɑz taɪɝd, ən i kəd nɑt si ɛni pleɪs əhɛɾ ə hɪm ɛniwɛɹ.

Dannil rubbed his tusk-like mustaches with a cold-reddened knuckle and eyed Arganda sideways, then exhaled heavily in a mist. "I'll watch him, Lord Perrin," he muttered, giving his cloak a hitch, "but no matter what you said about me being in charge, as soon as you're out of sight, he won't listen to a thing I say." Unfortunately, that was true. Perrin would rather have taken Arganda with him and left Gallenne here, but neither had been willing to accept that. The Ghealdanin did accept that men and horses would begin starving soon unless food and fodder were found somewhere, but he could not make himself spend a day farther from his queen than he already was. In some ways, he seemed even more frantic than Perrin, or maybe just more ready to give in to it. Left to himself, Arganda would have been edging a little nearer the Shaido every day until he was right under their noses. Perrin was ready to die to free Faile. Arganda just seemed ready to die. "Do what you can to keep him from doing anything stupid, Dannil." After a moment, he added, "As long as it doesn't come to blows." There was only so far he could expect Dannil to restrain the fellow, after all. There were three Ghealdanin for every Two Rivers man, and Faile would never be freed if it came to them killing each other. Perrin very nearly rested his head on Stayer's flank. Light, but he was tired, and he could not see any place ahead of him anywhere.

ə sloʊ klɑp ə hʊvz ənaʊns ði ɝaɪvəl ə mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪd, wɪð ðɛɹ θɹi wɔɹɾɝz ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɹæpt ɪn kloʊks ðət meɪd moʊst ʌv itʃ mæn vænɪʃ, əlɔŋ wɪð pɑɹɾ ə hɪz hɔɹs.

A slow clop of hooves announced the arrival of Masuri and Seonid, with their three Warders riding close behind wrapped in cloaks that made most of each man vanish, along with part of his horse.

boʊθ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɔɹ ʃɪmɝɪŋ sɪlk, ən ə hɛvi ɡoʊl nɛkləs, leɪɝz ə θɪk stʃɹænz, ʃoʊɾ ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə mɑsʊɝiz dɑɹk kloʊk. ə smɔl waɪt dʒuəl dæŋɡəld ɑntu siɑnɪdz fɔɹhɛd fɹəm ə faɪn ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn fæsən ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. ənʊɹə ɹɪlækst, sɛɾəlɪŋ mɔɹ izəli ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. bæk əmʌŋ ði il tɛns, ðə waɪz wʌnz stʊɾ ɪn ə laɪn wɑtʃɪŋ, sɪks tɔl wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz ɹæpt ɪn dɑɹk ʃɔlz.

Both Aes Sedai wore shimmering silk, and a heavy gold necklace, layers of thick strands, showed under the edge of Masuri's dark cloak. A small white jewel dangled onto Seonid's forehead from a fine golden chain fastened in her hair. Annoura relaxed, settling more easily in her saddle. Back among the Aiel tents, the Wise Ones stood in a line watching, six tall women with their heads wrapped in dark shawls.

ðə pipəl ə soʊ hæbɝ maɪt bi əbaʊɾ əz wɛlkəmɪŋ tə il əz ðə pipəl ə meɪɾən wəɾ əv bɪn, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd lɛɾ iðɝ sɪstɝ kʌm əloʊn. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðə læst ɹizən fəɹ weɪɾɪŋ. ðə sʌn wɑz ə ɹɛd-ɡoʊld ɹɪm ɑn ðə tʃɹitɑps.

The people of So Habor might be about as welcoming to Aiel as the people of Maiden would have been, but Perrin had not been sure the Wise Ones would let either sister come alone. They had been the last reason for waiting. The sun was a red-gold rim on the treetops.

"ðə sunɝ ðɛɹ, ðə sunɝ bæk," hi sɛd, klaɪmɪŋ ɪndə ðə beɪz sæɾəl. əz i ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡæp ðət hæd bɪn meɪd tə lɛt ðə kɑɹts aʊt, tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹipleɪs ðə mɪsɪŋ steɪks. noʊ wʌn læk fəɹ wɛɹinɪs wɪð mæsiməz pipəl nɪɹbaɪ.

"The sooner there, the sooner back," he said, climbing into the bay's saddle. As he rode through the gap that had been made to let the carts out, Two Rivers men were already beginning to replace the missing stakes. No one lacked for wariness with Masema's people nearby.

ɪt wɑz ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz tə ðə tʃɹilaɪn, bʌɾ ɪz aɪ kɑt muvmənt, sʌmwʌn ɑn ə hɔɹs slɪpɪŋ əweɪ ɪndə ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz bɪniθ ðə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹiz. wʌn ə mæsiməz wɑtʃɝz, noʊ daʊt, ɹeɪsɪŋ tə tɛl ðə pɹɑfət ðət pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn hæd lɛf ðə kæmp. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fæst i ɹoʊd, ðoʊ, hi kəd nɑt bi ɪn taɪm. ɪf mæsimə wɑntəd bɹəleɪn əɹ pɛɹɪn dɛd, əz sim laɪkli, hi wəɾ əv tə weɪɾ ɑn ənʌðɝ ɑpɝtunəɾi. ɡælɛn wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə teɪk ɛni tʃænsəz, ðoʊ. noʊ wʌn hæd sin haɪd nɔɹ toʊneɪlz ə sɑns əɹ dʒɛnʒɹ, bɹəleɪnz tu θifkætʃɝz, sɪns ðə deɪ ðeɪ feɪl tə ɹɪtɝn fɹəm mæsiməz kæmp, ən tə ɡælɛn ðət wɑz əz ʃʊɹ ə mɛsədʒ əz ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪn ə sæk. hi hæɾ ɪz lænsɝz spɹɛɾ ɪn ə ʃɑɹp-aɪd ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn bɹəleɪn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə tʃɹiz. ən ɝaʊn pɛɹɪn, tu, bʌt ðət wɑz oʊnli ɪnsɪdɛntəl. ɡɪvən ɪz wɪʃɪz, ɡælɛn wʊɾə bɹɔɾ ɔl naɪn hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ ʌv ɪz wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, əɹ bɛɾɝ jɛt, ɪn ɪz vju, tɔk bɹəleɪn aʊɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ. pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd ðæt, əz wɛl, wɪð noʊ bɛɾɝ lʌk. ðə wʊmən hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv lɪsnɪŋ, ðən duɪŋ ɪɡzækli əz ʃi wɪʃt. feɪl wɑz laɪk ðæt, tu. səmtaɪmz ə mæn dʒʌs hæd tə lɪv wɪð ɪt. moʊst ə ðə taɪm, sɪns ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə du.

It was a hundred paces to the treeline, but his eye caught movement, someone on a horse slipping away into the deeper shadows beneath the towering trees. One of Masema's watchers, no doubt, racing to tell the Prophet that Perrin and Berelain had left the camp. No matter how fast he rode, though, he could not be in time. If Masema wanted Berelain or Perrin dead, as seemed likely, he would have to wait on another opportunity. Gallenne was not about to take any chances, though. No one had seen hide nor toenails of Santes or Gendar, Berelain's two thiefcatchers, since the day they failed to return from Masema's camp, and to Gallenne that was as sure a message as their heads in a sack. He had his lancers spread in a sharp-eyed ring around Berelain before they reached the trees. And around Perrin, too, but that was only incidental. Given his wishes, Gallenne would have brought all nine hundred or so of his Winged Guards, or better yet, in his view, talked Berelain out of going. Perrin had tried that, as well, with no better luck. The woman had a way of listening, then doing exactly as she wished. Faile was like that, too. Sometimes a man just had to live with it. Most of the time, since there was nothing else to do.

ðə hjudʒ tʃɹiz ən stoʊn aʊtkɹɑps stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ bɹoʊk ʌp ðə fɔɹmeɪʃən, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə kʌlɝfəl saɪɾ ivən ɪn ðə dɪm laɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst, ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz floʊɾɪŋ ɑn laɪɾ ɛɹz ɪn slæntəd bimz ə sʌnlaɪt, ɹɛd-ɑɹmɝd ɹaɪɾɝz vænɪʃɪŋ moʊməntɛɹəli bɪhaɪn mæsɪv oʊks ən lɛðɝlifs. ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn, fɑloʊd baɪ ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz, ɔl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊdz ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ðən ðə mæn wɪð bɹəleɪnz bænɝ. kaɪɹən ən ðə bænɝ ʌv ɡildən keɪm ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪnd, hɪz mɛn dʒɹɛst ɪn nit, ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪnz, əɹ əz nɪɹ əz ðeɪ kəd mænədʒ.

The huge trees and stone outcrops sticking out of the snow broke up the formation, of course, but it was still a colorful sight even in the dim light of the forest, red streamers floating on light airs in slanted beams of sunlight, red-armored riders vanishing momentarily behind massive oaks and leatherleafs. The three Aes Sedai rode behind Perrin and Berelain, followed by their Warders, all watching the woods around them, and then the man with Berelain's banner. Kireyin and the banner of Ghealdan came a little behind, his men dressed in neat, shining lines, or as near as they could manage.

ðə fɔɹəsts oʊpənnəs wɑz ə dɪsɛpʃən, ən ɪl suɾəd tə nit laɪnz ən bɹaɪt bænɝz, bʌɾ æɾ ɪn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlks ən dʒɛmz ən ə kɹaʊn ən wɔɹɾɝz ɪn ðoʊz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊks, ən ɪt wɑz ə moʊst ɪmpɹɛsɪv saɪt. pɛɹɪn kəɾ əv læft, ðoʊ wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ mɝθ.

The forest's openness was a deception, and ill suited to neat lines and bright banners, but add in embroidered silks and gems and a crown and Warders in those color-shifting cloaks, and it was a most impressive sight. Perrin could have laughed, though without much mirth.

bɹəleɪn sim tə sɛns ɪz θɔts. "wɛn jə ɡoʊ tə baɪ ə sæk ə flaʊɝ," ʃi sɛd, "wɛɹ pleɪn wʊl soʊ ðə sɛlɝ θɪŋks jə kæn əfɔɹd tə peɪ ɛni mɔɹ ðən jə mʌst. wən jəɹ æftɝ flaʊɝ baɪ ðə wæɡoʊnloʊd, wɛɹ dʒuəlz soʊ ʃi θɪŋks jə kən əfɔɹd tə kʌm bæk fəɹ ɔl ʃi kən leɪ hænz ɑn." pɛɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd ə læf ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. ɪt saʊndəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk sʌmθɪŋ mæstɝ luhən hæd toʊl hɪm, wʌns, wɪð ə nʌdʒ ɪn ðə ɹɪbz tə seɪ ɪt wɑz ə dʒoʊk ən ə lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪ ðət sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. dʒɹɛs pʊɹ wən jə wɑn ə smɔl feɪvɝ, ən faɪn wən jə wɑn ə lɑɹdʒ wʌn. hi wɑz vɛɹi ɡlæd bɹəleɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ smɛld laɪk ə hʌntɪŋ wʊlf. ət lis ðət tʊk wʌn wɝi ɔf ɪz maɪnd.

Berelain seemed to sense his thoughts. "When you go to buy a sack of flour," she said, "wear plain wool so the seller thinks you can't afford to pay any more than you must. When you're after flour by the wagonload, wear jewels so she thinks you can afford to come back for all she can lay hands on." Perrin snorted a laugh in spite of himself. It sounded very much like something Master Luhhan had told him, once, with a nudge in the ribs to say it was a joke and a look in his eye that said it was a little more. Dress poor when you want a small favor, and fine when you want a large one. He was very glad Berelain no longer smelled like a hunting wolf. At least that took one worry off his mind.

ðeɪ sun kɑɾ ʌp tə ðə teɪl ɛn ə ðə kɑɹts, ə laɪn ðət wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ muvɪŋ baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. ækswɝk ən swɛt hæd ɹimuv ðə tʃɹiz ʃɪɹɾ ɔf baɪ ɡeɪtweɪz ən meɪɾ ə lɪɾəl klɪɹɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kɹaʊɾəd ivən bɪfɔɹ ɡælɛn spɹɛɾ ɪz ɹɪŋ ə lænsɝz ɝaʊn ɪt feɪsɪŋ aʊtwɝd. peɪdʒɝ nild wɑz ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi, ə fɑpɪʃ mʊɹændiən wɪð ɪz mʌstæʃ wæks tə pɔɪns, ɑn ə dæpəl ɡɛldɪŋ. hɪz koʊt wəd də fəɹ ɛniwʌn u hæd nɑt sin ən æʃəmən bɪfɔɹ; ði oʊnli ʌðɝ wʌn i hæd wɑz blæk əz wɛl, ən ət list i hæd noʊ kɑlɝ pɪnz tə mɑɹk ɪm aʊt. ðə snoʊ wɑz nɑt dip, bʌt ðə twɛnti tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn lɛd baɪ wɪl ælsin wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, tu, ɹæðɝ ðən stændɪŋ ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ fit tə fɹiz ɪn ðɛɹ buts. ðeɪ lʊkt ə hɑɹɾɝ lɑt ðən ðə fɛloʊz u hæd lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪð hɪm, lɔŋboʊz slʌŋ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ bæks, bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝz ən sɔɹdz ə vɛɹiəs dɪskɹɪpʃənz ət ðɛɹ bɛls. pɛɹɪn hoʊpt i kəd sɛn əm hoʊm sun, əɹ bɛɾɝ, teɪk əm hoʊm.

They soon caught up to the tail end of the carts, a line that was no longer moving by the time they reached the Traveling ground. Axework and sweat had removed the trees sheared off by gateways and made a little clearing, but it was crowded even before Gallenne spread his ring of lancers around it facing outward. Pager Neald was there already, a foppish Murandian with his mustache waxed to points, on a dapple gelding. His coat would do for anyone who had not seen an Asha'man before; the only other one he had was black as well, and at least he had no collar pins to mark him out. The snow was not deep, but the twenty Two Rivers men led by Wil al'Seen were on their horses, too, rather than standing and waiting for their feet to freeze in their boots. They looked a harder lot than the fellows who had left the Two Rivers with him, longbows slung across their backs, bristling quivers and swords of various descriptions at their belts. Perrin hoped he could send them home soon, or better, take them home.

moʊst wɝ bælənsɪŋ ə pɑlɹm oʊvɝ ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, bʌt tɑɾ ɑlkɑɹ ən flæn bɑɹstɪɹ kæɹid bænɝz, pɛɹɪnz oʊn ɹɛd wʊlfhɛɾ ən ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə meɪnɛðɝən. tɑdz hɛvi dʒɔ wɑz sɛt stʌbɝnli, ən flæn, ə tɔl skɪni fɛloʊ fɹəm ʌp tə wɑtʃ hɪl, lʊk sʌlən. laɪkli hi hæd nɑt wɑntəd ðə dʒɑb. meɪbi tɑd hæd nɑt, iðɝ. wɪl ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz oʊpən, ɪnəsən lʊks ðət ful soʊ mɛni ɡɝlz bæk hoʊm - wɪl laɪk tu mʌtʃ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ɪz koʊɾ ət fistdeɪz, ən i pjʊɹli lʌvd ɹaɪɾɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðoʊz bænɝz, pɹɑbli ɪn ðə hoʊp səm wʊmən wəd θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ ɪz - bʌt pɛɹɪn lɛɾ ɪt pæs. hi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd ði ʌðɝ θɹi pipəl ɪn ðə klɪɹɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ ðən i hæd ðə bænɝz. hoʊldɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪm əz ɪf ðə maɪl bɹiz wɝ ə ɡeɪl, beɪlwɝ klʌmsəli hild ɪz blʌnt-noʊzd ɹoʊn fɔɹwɝd tə mit pɛɹɪn. tu ʌv feɪlz hæŋɝz-ɑn tʃɹeɪld æftɝ ɪm wɪð dɪfaɪən ɪkspɹɛʃənz. mɛdɔɹz blu aɪz lʊkt ɑɾ ɪn əɹ dɑɹk tɛɹən feɪs, bʌt ðɛn, hɝ koʊt, wɪð ɪts pʌfi ɡɹin-stʃɹaɪp slivz, lʊkt ɑɾ ɑn əɹ boʊsəmi fɹeɪm. ðə dɔɾɝ ʌv ə haɪ lɔɹd, ʃi wɑz ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə noʊbəlwʊmən, ən mɛnz kloʊðɪŋ dʒʌs dɪd nɑt sut hɝ. lɑɾən, kɛɹhinɪn ən peɪl ɪn ə koʊɾ ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk əz nilz, ðoʊ mɑɹkt wɪð fɔɹ slæʃɪz ə ɹɛɾ ən blu əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst, wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ tɔlɝ ðən ʃi, ən ðə weɪ hi snɪfəld wɪð ə koʊld ən ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz ʃɑɹp noʊz meɪɾ ɪm lʊk mʌtʃ lɛs kɑmpəɾənt. niðɝ wɔɹ ə sɔɹd, ənʌðɝ sɝpɹaɪz.

Most were balancing a polearm over their saddles, but Tod al'Caar and Flann Barstere carried banners, Perrin's own Red Wolfhead and the Red Eagle of Manetheren. Tod's heavy jaw was set stubbornly, and Flann, a tall skinny fellow from up to Watch Hill, looked sullen. Likely he had not wanted the job. Maybe Tod had not, either. Wil gave Perrin one of those open, innocent looks that fooled so many girls back home - Wil liked too much embroidery on his coat at feastdays, and he purely loved riding ahead of those banners, probably in the hope some woman would think they were his - but Perrin let it pass. He had not expected the other three people in the clearing any more than he had the banners. Holding his cloak around him as if the mild breeze were a gale, Balwer clumsily heeled his blunt-nosed roan forward to meet Perrin. Two of Faile's hangers-on trailed after him with defiant expressions. Medore's blue eyes looked odd in her dark Tairen face, but then, her coat, with its puffy green-striped sleeves, looked odd on her bosomy frame. The daughter of a High Lord, she was every inch a noblewoman, and men's clothing just did not suit her. Latian, Cairhienin and pale in a coat almost as dark as Neald's, though marked with four slashes of red and blue across the chest, was not much taller than she, and the way he sniffled with a cold and rubbed at his sharp nose made him look much less competent. Neither wore a sword, another surprise.

"maɪ lɔɹd; maɪ leɪɾi fɝst," beɪlwɝ sɛɾ ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs, dʌkɪŋ ə baʊ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ə spɛɹoʊ bɑbɪŋ ɑn ə bɹæntʃ. hɪz aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, bʌt ðət wɑz ði oʊnli saɪn i ɡeɪv ðəɾ i wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə sɪstɝz. "maɪ lɔɹd, aɪ ɹɪkɔl ðəɾ aɪ hæv ən əkweɪntəns ɪn ðɪs soʊ hæbɝ.

"My Lord; my Lady First," Balwer said in that dry voice, ducking a bow in his saddle, a sparrow bobbing on a branch. His eyes flickered toward the Aes Sedai behind them, but that was the only sign he gave that he was aware of the sisters. "My Lord, I recalled that I have an acquaintance in this So Habor.

ə kʌtlɝ u tʃɹævəlz wɪð ɪz wɛɹz, bʌɾ i meɪ bi ət hoʊm, ən aɪv nɑt sin ɪm ɪn sɛvɹəl jɪɹz." ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm i hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛnʃən hævɪŋ ə fɹɛn ɛniwɛɹ, ən ə taʊn bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə nɔɹθ ʌv ɔltɑɹə simd ə pəkjuljɝ pleɪs fəɹ ɪt, bʌt pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. hi səspɛktəd ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə ðɪs fɹɛn ðən beɪlwɝ wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ɑn. hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə səspɛk ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə beɪlwɝ ðən ðə mæn lɛɾ ɑn.

A cutler who travels with his wares, but he may be at home, and I've not seen him in several years." This was the first time he had ever mentioned having a friend anywhere, and a town buried in the north of Altara seemed a peculiar place for it, but Perrin nodded. He suspected there was more to this friend than Balwer was letting on. He was beginning to suspect there was more to Balwer than the man let on.

"æn jəɹ kəmpænjənz, mæstɝ beɪlwɝ?" bɹəleɪnz feɪs steɪd smuð ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ fɝ-laɪn kaʊl, bʌt ʃi smɛld əmjuzd. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət feɪl hæd juzd əɹ jʌŋ fɑloʊɝz əz spaɪz ən wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət pɛɹɪn meɪd ðə seɪm jus ə ðɛm. "ðeɪ wɑntəɾ ən aʊɾɪŋ, maɪ leɪɾi fɝst," ðə boʊni lɪɾəl mæn ɹɪplaɪd blænli. "aɪ wɪl vaʊtʃ fəɹ ðɛm, maɪ lɔɹd. ðeɪv pɹɑməs tə kɑz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl, ən ðeɪ meɪ lɝn sʌmθɪŋ." hi smɛld əmjuzd, tu - ə mʌsti smɛl, ʌv kɔɹs, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɪm - ðoʊ wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən. beɪlwɝ nu ʃi nu, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt pliz hɪm, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ meɪɾ oʊpən ɹɛfɝəns tə ðə fækt, wɪtʃ dɪd. ðəɹ dɛfənətli wɑz mɔɹ tə beɪlwɝ ðən i lɛɾ ɑn.

"And your companions, Master Balwer?" Berelain's face stayed smooth inside her fur-lined cowl, but she smelled amused. She knew very well that Faile had used her young followers as spies and was sure that Perrin made the same use of them. "They wanted an outing, my Lady First," the bony little man replied blandly. "I will vouch for them, my Lord. They've promised to cause no trouble, and they may learn something." He smelled amused, too - a musty smell, of course, coming from him - though with a touch of irritation. Balwer knew she knew, which did not please him, but she never made open reference to the fact, which did. There definitely was more to Balwer than he let on.

ðə mæn mʌst əv ɪz ɹizənz fəɹ teɪkɪŋ əm əlɔŋ. hi hæd mænədʒ tə teɪk ʌp ɔl ə feɪlz jʌŋ fɑloʊɝz wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ, ən hæɾ əm ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ən wɑtʃɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ɡildænɪn ən ðə minɝz ən ivən ði il. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɪm, wʌt jəɹ fɹɛnz sɛɾ ən dɪd kəd bi əz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ əz wʌt jəɹ ɛnəmiz plænd, ən ðət wɑz wən jə wɝ ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ jəɹ fɹɛnz. ʌv kɔɹs, bɹəleɪn nu ðəɾ əɹ pipəl wɝ biɪŋ spaɪɾ ɑn. ən beɪlwɝ nu ʃi nu ðæt, tu. ən ʃi nu ðət hi. . . . ɪt wɑz ɔl tu səfɪstəkeɪɾɪd fəɹ ə kʌntʃɹi blæksmɪθ. "wɝ weɪstɪŋ taɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "oʊpən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, nild."

The man must have his reasons for taking them along. He had managed to take up all of Faile's young followers one way and another, and had them eavesdropping and watching among the Ghealdanin and the Mayeners and even the Aiel. According to him, what your friends said and did could be as interesting as what your enemies planned, and that was when you were sure they were your friends. Of course, Berelain knew that her people were being spied on. And Balwer knew she knew that, too. And she knew that he. . . . It was all too sophisticated for a country blacksmith. "We're wasting time," Perrin said. "Open the gateway, Neald."

ði æʃəmən ɡɹɪn əɾ ɪm ən stʃɹoʊkt ɪz wæks mʌstæʃɪz nild ɡɹɪn tu mʌtʃ sɪns ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ faʊnd; meɪbi hi wɑz iɡɝ tə kʌm tə ɡɹɪps wɪð əm - hi ɡɹɪn ən dʒɛstʃɝd ɡɹænli wɪð wʌn hænd. "æz jə kəmænd," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə tʃɪɹfəl vɔɪs, ən ðə fəmɪljɝ sɪlvɝi slæʃ ə laɪɾ əpɪɹd, waɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ.

The Asha'man grinned at him and stroked his waxed mustaches Neald grinned too much since the Shaido were found; maybe he was eager to come to grips with them - he grinned and gestured grandly with one hand. "As you command," he said in a cheerful voice, and the familiar silvery slash of light appeared, widening into a hole in the air.

wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd θɹu ɪndə ə snoʊ-kʌvɝd fild, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə loʊ stoʊn wɔl, ɪn ɹoʊlɪŋ kʌntʃɹi ðət simd ɔlmoʊs tʃɹiləs kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə fɔɹəst i hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd, dʒʌst ə fju maɪlz fɹəm soʊ hæbɝ ənlɛs nil hæd meɪɾ ə səbstæntʃəl ɛɹɝ. ɪf i hæd, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i maɪt pʊl ðoʊz ful mʌstæʃɪz ɹaɪɾ ɔf ðə mænz feɪs. haʊ kəd ðə fɛloʊ bi tʃɪɹfəl?

Without waiting for anyone else, Perrin rode through into a snow-covered field, surrounded by a low stone wall, in rolling country that seemed almost treeless compared with the forest he had left behind, just a few miles from So Habor unless Neald had made a substantial error. If he had, Perrin thought he might pull those fool mustaches right off the man's face. How could the fellow be cheerful?

sun, ðoʊ, hi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɛs bɪniθ ə ɡɹeɪ klaʊɾi skaɪ, əlɔŋ ə snoʊi ɹoʊd wɪð ðə haɪwil kɑɹts tʃɹʌnlɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪn ə laɪn æftɝ ɪm ən ɝli-mɔɹnɪŋ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ əhɛd. steɪɝ tʌɡd ət ðə ɹeɪnz, wɑntɪŋ tə ɹʌn, bʌt pɛɹɪn hɛld ɪm tə ə stɛɾi wɔk, noʊ fæstɝ ðən ðə kɑɹθɔɹsɪz kəd mænədʒ. ɡælɛnz minɝz hæd tə kɹɔs filz bɪsaɪd ðə ɹoʊd tə meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm ən bɹəleɪn, ən ðət mɛnt ɡɛɾɪŋ pæs ðə loʊ wɔlz ə ɹʌf stoʊn ðət dɪvaɪɾəd fil fɹəm fild.

Soon, though, he was riding west beneath a gray cloudy sky, along a snowy road with the highwheeled carts trundling along in a line after him and early-morning shadows stretching ahead. Stayer tugged at the reins, wanting to run, but Perrin held him to a steady walk, no faster than the carthorses could manage. Gallenne's Mayeners had to cross fields beside the road to maintain their ring around him and Berelain, and that meant getting past the low walls of rough stone that divided field from field.

səm hæd ɡeɪts fɹəm wʌn fɑɹmɝz pɹɑpɝɾi tə ðə nɛkst, pɹɑbli tə əlaʊ ʃɛɹɪŋ plaʊ-timz, ən ʌðɝz ðeɪ dʒʌmp flæmbɔɪənli wɪð ðə stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðɛɹ lænsɪz flaɪɪŋ, ɹɪskɪŋ ðɛɹ ænəməlz lɛɡz ən ðɛɹ nɛks. pɛɹɪn kɛɹd ðə lɛs əbaʊt ðɛɹ nɛks, ɪn tʃɹuθ. wɪl ən ðə tu fulz kæɹiɪŋ ðə wʊlfhɛɾ ən ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl dʒɔɪn ðə minɝ bænɝmən bɪhaɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz, bʌt ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stʃɹʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz aʊt flæŋkɪŋ ðə laɪn ə kɑɹts. ðəɹ wɝ fɑɹ tu mɛni kɑɹts fəɹ fjuɝ ðən twɛnti mɛn tə ɡɑɹd, jɛt ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz wəd fil iziɝ siɪŋ ðɛm. nɑt ðəɾ ɛniwʌn ɪkspɛktəd bɹɪɡænz, əɹ ʃeɪɾoʊ fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, bʌt noʊ wʌn fɛl kʌmftəɹbəl aʊtsaɪd ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðə kæmp. ɪn ɛni keɪs, hɪɹ ðeɪ wəd bi eɪbəl tə si ɛni θɹɛt wɛl bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹitʃt ðɛm.

Some had gates from one farmer's property to the next, probably to allow sharing plow-teams, and others they jumped flamboyantly with the streamers on their lances flying, risking their animal's legs and their necks. Perrin cared the less about their necks, in truth. Wil and the two fools carrying the Wolfhead and the Red Eagle joined the Mayener bannerman behind the Aes Sedai and Warders, but the other Two Rivers men strung themselves out flanking the line of carts. There were far too many carts for fewer than twenty men to guard, yet the cart drivers would feel easier seeing them. Not that anyone expected brigands, or Shaido for that matter, but no one felt comfortable outside the protection of the camp. In any case, here they would be able to see any threat well before it reached them.

ðə loʊ ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz dɪd nɑt ɹɪli əlaʊ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ vju, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz fɑɹm kʌntʃɹi, wɪð stɝɾi θætʃ-ɹuf stoʊn haʊsəz ən bɑɹnz skæɾɝd əmʌŋ ðə filz, ən nʌθɪŋ ʌv waɪlnəs əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɛniwɛɹ. ivən moʊst ə ðə smɔl θɪkəts klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə sloʊps wɝ kɑpaɪs fəɹ faɪɝwʊd. bʌɾ ɪt stʃɹʌk pɛɹɪn sʌɾənli ðət ðə snoʊ ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm wɑz nɑt fɹɛʃ; jɛt ði oʊnli tʃɹæks wɝ ðoʊz meɪd baɪ ɡælɛnz fɔɹaɪɾɝz. noʊ wʌn muvd ɝaʊn ɛni ʌv ðoʊz dɑɹk haʊsəz ən bɑɹnz; noʊ smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm ɛni ʌv ðə θɪk tʃɪmniz. ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd simd æbsəlutli stɪl ən æbsəlutli ɛmpti. ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk stɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stænd.

The low rolling hills did not really allow a very long view, but it was farm country, with sturdy thatch-roofed stone houses and barns scattered among the fields, and nothing of wildness about it anywhere. Even most of the small thickets clinging to the slopes were coppiced for firewood. But it struck Perrin suddenly that the snow on the road ahead of him was not fresh; yet the only tracks were those made by Gallenne's foreriders. No one moved around any of those dark houses and barns; no smoke rose from any of the thick chimneys. The countryside seemed absolutely still and absolutely empty. The hair on the back of his neck stirred, trying to stand.

ən ɛkskləmeɪʃən fɹəm wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪɾ ɪm lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən i fɑloʊd mɑsʊɝiz pɔɪntɪŋ fɪŋɡɝ nɔɹθ tə ə ʃeɪp flaɪɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɹ. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn teɪkən fəɹ ə lɑɹdʒ bæɾ ət fɝst ɡlæns, swipɪŋ istwɝɾ ɑn lɔŋ ɹɪbd wɪŋz, ə stʃɹeɪnʒ bæt wɪð ə lɔŋ nɛk ən ə lɔŋ θɪn teɪl tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ɡælɛn bɑɹkt ən oʊθ ən pɹɛst ɪz lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs tə hɪz aɪ. pɛɹɪn kəd si ɪt wɛl ɪnʌf əneɪɾɪd, ən ivən meɪk aʊt ðə fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə hjumən biɪŋ klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə kɹitʃɝz bæk, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪt laɪk ə hɔɹs.

An exclamation from one of the Aes Sedai made him look over his shoulder, and he followed Masuri's pointing finger north to a shape flying through the air. It might have been taken for a large bat at first glance, sweeping eastward on long ribbed wings, a strange bat with a long neck and a long thin tail trailing behind. Gallenne barked an oath and pressed his looking glass to his eye. Perrin could see it well enough unaided, and even make out the figure of a human being clinging to the creature's back, riding it like a horse.

"sintʃæn," bɹəleɪn bɹiðd, boʊθ əɹ vɔɪs ən ðə smɛl ə hɝ wɝid.

"Seanchan," Berelain breathed, both her voice and the smell of her worried.

pɛɹɪn twɪstəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə wɑtʃ ðə θɪŋz flaɪɾ əntɪl ðə ɡlɛɹ ə ðə sʌnɹaɪz meɪɾ ɪm tɝn əweɪ. "nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs," hi sɛd. ɪf nil hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk, hi wəd stʃɹæŋɡəl ðə mæn.

Perrin twisted in his saddle to watch the thing's flight until the glare of the sunrise made him turn away. "Nothing to do with us," he said. If Neald had made a mistake, he would strangle the man.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks

CHAPTER 26

ɪn soʊ hæbɝ ɛs ɪt hæpənd, nild, hu hæd hæd tə ɹɪmeɪn tə hoʊl ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpən tɪl kaɪɹən ən ðə ɡildænɪn wɝ θɹu, hæd pleɪs ðə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ vɛɹi kloʊs tə wɛɹ i eɪmd. hi ən kaɪɹən kɑɾ ʌp əɾ ə ɡæləp dʒʌst əz pɛɹɪn tɑpt ə ɹaɪz ən dʒɹu ɹeɪn wɪð ðə taʊn ə soʊ hæbɝ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ə smɔl ɹɪvɝ kɹɔs baɪ ə pɛɹ ʌv ɑɹtʃɪŋ tɪmbɝ bɹɪdʒəz. pɛɹɪn wɑz noʊ soʊlʒɝ, bʌɾ i nu ɹaɪɾ əweɪ waɪ mæsimə hæd lɛf ðɪs pleɪs əloʊn. hɑɹɾ əɡɛns ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðə taʊn hæd tu mæsɪv stoʊn wɔlz dɑɾəd wɪð taʊɝz ɝaʊn ɪt, ði ɪnɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ tɔlɝ ðən ði aʊɾɝ. ə pɛɹ ə bɑɹdʒəz wɝ taɪd tə ə lɔŋ wɔɹf ðət ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ wɔl fɹəm bɹɪdʒ tə bɹɪdʒ, jɛt ðə waɪd bɹɪdʒ ɡeɪts, aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ən kloʊz taɪt, sim tə bi ði oʊnli oʊpənɪŋz ɪn ðəɾ ɪkspæns ə ɹʌf ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, ən bæɾəlmənts tɑp ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ʌv ɪt. bɪl tə hoʊld ɔf ɡɹiɾi neɪbɝɪŋ noʊbəlz, soʊ hæbɝ wʊɾə hæd lɪɾəl fɪɹ ə ðə pɹɑfəts ɹæbəl ivən ɪf ðeɪ keɪm baɪ θaʊzənz. ɛniwʌn wɑntɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ɪndə ðɪs taʊn wəd nid sidʒ ɛnʒənz ən peɪʃəns, ən mæsimə wɑz mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl tɛɹɝaɪzɪŋ vɪlədʒəz ən taʊnz wɪθaʊt wɔlz əɹ dɪfɛnsəz.

In So Habor s it happened, Neald, who had had to remain to hold the gateway open till Kireyin and the Ghealdanin were through, had placed the hole in the air very close to where he aimed. He and Kireyin caught up at a gallop just as Perrin topped a rise and drew rein with the town of So Habor in front of him, on the other side of a small river crossed by a pair of arching timber bridges. Perrin was no soldier, but he knew right away why Masema had left this place alone. Hard against the river, the town had two massive stone walls dotted with towers around it, the inner rising taller than the outer. A pair of barges were tied to a long wharf that ran along the river wall from bridge to bridge, yet the wide bridge gates, iron-strapped and closed tight, seemed to be the only openings in that expanse of rough gray stone, and battlements topped the whole length of it. Built to hold off greedy neighboring nobles, So Habor would have had little fear of the Prophet's rabble even if they came by thousands.
