Anyone wanting to break into this town would need siege engines and patience, and Masema was more comfortable terrorizing villages and towns without walls or defenses.

"wɛl, ɪts ɡlæɾ aɪm tə si pipəl ɑn ðə wɔlz oʊvɝ ðɛɹ," nil sɛd. "aɪ wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðɪs kʌntʃɹi wɑz dɛɾ ən bɛɹid." hi saʊndəɾ oʊnli hæf dʒoʊkɪŋ, ən ɪz ɡɹɪn lʊk fɔɹst.

"Well, it's glad I am to see people on the walls over there," Neald said. "I was beginning to think everyone in this country was dead and buried." He sounded only half joking, and his grin looked forced.

"æz lɔŋ əz ðəɹ əlaɪv ɪnʌf tə sɛl ɡɹeɪn," kaɪɹən mɝmɝɾ ɪn ɪz neɪzəl, bɔɹd vɔɪs.

"As long as they're alive enough to sell grain," Kireyin murmured in his nasal, bored voice.

ənbəklɪŋ ɪz sɪlvɝi, waɪɾɪplumd hɛlmət, hi lɪftəɾ ɪt daʊn tə ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl. hɪz aɪz swɛpt pæs pɛɹɪn ən pɔz bɹifli ɑn bɹəleɪn bɪfɔɹ i twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə ædʒɹɛs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə seɪm wɪɹi toʊn. "ɑɹ wi gɑnə sɪt hɪɹ, əɹ ɡoʊ daʊn?" bɹəleɪn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm, ə deɪnʒɝəs lʊk, əz ə mæn wɪð ɛni bɹeɪnz wəd si. kaɪɹən dɪd nɑt si.

Unbuckling his silvery, whiteplumed helmet, he lifted it down to the tall pommel of his saddle. His eyes swept past Perrin and paused briefly on Berelain before he twisted around to address the Aes Sedai in the same weary tone. "Are we going to sit here, or go down?" Berelain arched an eyebrow at him, a dangerous look, as a man with any brains would see. Kireyin did not see.

pɛɹɪnz hækəlz wɝ stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stænd, ðə mɔɹ soʊ sɪns siɪŋ ðə taʊn. meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ðət wɑz wʊlf, dɪsləkɪŋ wɔlz. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ. ðə pipəl ətɑp ðə wɔlz pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd ðɛm, ən səm hɛld lʊkɪŋ ɡlæsəz. ðoʊz, ət list, wəd bi eɪbəl tə meɪk aʊt ðə bænɝz klɪɹli. ɛvɹiwʌn wəd bi eɪbəl tə si ðə soʊlʒɝz, wɪð ðə stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðɛɹ lænsɪz floʊɾɪŋ ɑn ə mɔɹnɪŋ bɹiz. ən ðə fɝs fju kɑɹts ə ðə laɪn ðət stʃɹɛtʃt daʊn ðə ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ saɪt. meɪbi ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm ðə fɑɹmz wɑz kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə ðə taʊn. "wi dɪdn kʌm hɪɹ tə sɪt," hi sɛd.

Perrin's hackles were still trying to stand, the more so since seeing the town. Maybe it was just the part of him that was wolf, disliking walls. But he did not think so. The people atop the walls pointed toward them, and some held looking glasses. Those, at least, would be able to make out the banners clearly. Everyone would be able to see the soldiers, with the streamers on their lances floating on a morning breeze. And the first few carts of the line that stretched down the road out of their sight. Maybe everyone from the farms was crowded into the town. "We didn't come here to sit," he said.

bɹəleɪn ən ənʊɹə bɪtwin əm hæd leɪɾ aʊt haʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ soʊ hæbɝ. ðə loʊkəl lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi hæd ʃʊɹli hɝɾ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɛpɹədeɪʃənz nɑt mɛni maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ ə ðɛm, ən ðeɪ maɪɾ əv hɝɾ ə ðə pɹɑfəts pɹɛzəns ɪn ɔltɑɹə, tu. iðɝ θɪŋ wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛniwʌn wɛɹi; təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ maɪt bi ɪnʌf tə meɪk pipəl lus æɹoʊz ən weɪt tɪl æftɝ tə æsk u ðeɪ hæd ʃɑt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt wɑz haɪli ənlaɪkli ðeɪ wəd wɛlkəm aʊtlæn soʊlʒɝz θɹu ðɛɹ ɡeɪts ət ðə moʊmənt. ðə lænsɝz ɹɪmeɪn spɹɛɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɹaɪz, ə ʃoʊ ðət ðiz vɪzəɾɝz pəzɛst səm ɑɹmd maɪɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ tʃoʊz nɑt tə ɛmplɔɪ ɪt. nɑt ðət soʊ hæbɝ wəd bi oʊvɝli ɪmpɹɛs baɪ ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn, bʌt ðə bɝnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ ə ðə ɡildænɪn ən ðə ɹɛɾ ɑɹmɝ ə ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz sɛd ðə vɪzəɾɝz wɝ nɑt wɑndɝɪŋ tʃɹɪkstɝz. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wəɾ ɪmpɹɛs noʊ wʌn əntɪl ðeɪ juz ðɛɹ baʊz, soʊ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn bæk wɪð ðə kɑɹts, tə hoʊld ʌp ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz' spɪɹəts. ɪt wɑz ɔl ən ɪlæbɹət bɪɾ ə nɑnsɛns, flʌf ən fɛðɝz, bʌt pɛɹɪn wɑz ə kʌntʃɹi blæksmɪθ noʊ mæɾɝ u kɔld ɪm lɔɹd. ðə fɝst ə min ən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃəd noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊɾ ɪn ə θɪŋ laɪk ðɪs.

Berelain and Annoura between them had laid out how to approach So Habor. The local lord or lady had surely heard of Shaido depredations not many miles to the north of them, and they might have heard of the Prophet's presence in Altara, too. Either thing was enough to make anyone wary; together, they might be enough to make people loose arrows and wait till after to ask who they had shot. In any case, it was highly unlikely they would welcome outland soldiers through their gates at the moment. The lancers remained spread along the rise, a show that these visitors possessed some armed might even if they chose not to employ it. Not that So Habor would be overly impressed by a hundred men, but the burnished armor of the Ghealdanin and the red armor of the Winged Guards said the visitors were not wandering tricksters. The Two Rivers men would impress no one until they used their bows, so they remained back with the carts, to hold up the cart drivers' spirits. It was all an elaborate bit of nonsense, fluff and feathers, but Perrin was a country blacksmith no matter who called him lord. The First of Mayene and an Aes Sedai should know what they were about in a thing like this.

ɡælɛn lɛd ðə weɪ daʊn tə ðə ɹɪvɝ əɾ ə sloʊ wɔk, bɹaɪt kɹɪmzən hɛlmət ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl, hɪz bæk stʃɹeɪt. pɛɹɪn ən bɹəleɪn ɹoʊɾ ə lɪɾəl weɪ bɪhaɪnd, wɪð siɑnɪd bɪtwin əm ən mɑsʊɝi ən ənʊɹə tə iðɝ saɪd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ðɛɹ hʊdz θɹoʊn bæk soʊ ɛniwʌn ɑn ðoʊz wɔlz u kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs wəɾ əv ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə si θɹi. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ wɛlkəmd moʊs pleɪsəz, ivən wɛɹ pipəl ɹɪli wəd ɹæðɝ nɑt. ət ðɛɹ bæks keɪm ɔl fɔɹ bænɝmɪn, wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝz speɪst əmʌŋ əm ɪn ðɛɹ aɪ-ɹɛntʃɪŋ kloʊks. ən kaɪɹən wɪð ɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ hɛlmət bælənst ɑn ɪz θaɪ, saʊɝ-maʊðd ət biɪŋ ɹɛləɡeɪɾɪd tə ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝz ən naʊ ən ðən ɡlɛɹɪŋ koʊldli daʊn ɪz noʊz ət beɪlwɝ, hu tʃɹeɪld ət ðə ɹɪɹ wɪð ɪz tu kəmpænjənz.

Gallenne led the way down to the river at a slow walk, bright crimson helmet resting on his saddle, his back straight. Perrin and Berelain rode a little way behind, with Seonid between them and Masuri and Annoura to either side, the Aes Sedai with their hoods thrown back so anyone on those walls who could recognize an Aes Sedai face would have the opportunity to see three. Aes Sedai were welcomed most places, even where people really would rather not. At their backs came all four bannermen, with the Warders spaced among them in their eye-wrenching cloaks. And Kireyin with his shining helmet balanced on his thigh, sour-mouthed at being relegated to riding with the Warders and now and then glaring coldly down his nose at Balwer, who trailed at the rear with his two companions.

noʊ wʌn hæd toʊl beɪlwɝ i kəd kʌm, jɛt noʊ wʌn hæd sɛɾ i kəd nɑt. hi bɑbd ə baʊ wɛnɛvɝ ðə noʊbəlmən lʊkt ət hɪm, ðən wɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə taʊn wɔlz əhɛd. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt ʃeɪk ɪz ʌnizinəs əz ðeɪ dʒɹu nɪɹɝ ðə taʊn. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz klæɾɝd hɑloʊli ɑn ðə sʌðɝnmoʊs bɹɪdʒ, ə waɪd stʃɹʌktʃɝ ðət ɹoʊz haɪ ɪnʌf əbʌv ðə swɪftfloʊɪŋ ɹɪvɝ tə lɛɾ ə bɑɹdʒ laɪk ðoʊz taɪd tə ðə wɔɹf pæs izəli ʌndɝniθ ɑn swips. niðɝ ə ðə bɹɔd blʌf-baʊd kɹæf hæɾ ɛni pɹəvɪʒən fəɹ stɛpɪŋ ə mæst. wʌn ə ðoʊz bɑɹdʒəz hæd sɛɾəld dip ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, slæntɪŋ əɡɛns tɔt mʊɹɪŋ ɹoʊps, ən ði ʌðɝ sʌmhaʊ lʊkt əbændənd, tu. ə ɹæŋk, saʊɝ smɛl ɪn ði ɛɹ meɪɾ ɪm ɹʌb əɾ ɪz noʊz. noʊ wʌn ɛls sim tə noʊɾəs.

No one had told Balwer he could come, yet no one had said he could not. He bobbed a bow whenever the nobleman looked at him, then went back to studying the town walls ahead. Perrin could not shake his uneasiness as they drew nearer the town. The horses' hooves clattered hollowly on the southernmost bridge, a wide structure that rose high enough above the swiftflowing river to let a barge like those tied to the wharf pass easily underneath on sweeps. Neither of the broad bluff-bowed craft had any provision for stepping a mast. One of those barges had settled deep in the water, slanting against taut mooring ropes, and the other somehow looked abandoned, too. A rank, sour smell in the air made him rub at his nose. No one else seemed to notice.

nɪɹ ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, ɡælɛn dʒɹu ʌp. ðə kloʊzd ɡeɪts, kʌvɝd wɪð blæk aɪɝn stʃɹæps ə fʊt waɪd, wʊɾə fɔɹst ə pɔz ɛniweɪ. "wi hæv hɝɾ ə ðə tʃɹʌbəlz pleɪɡɪŋ ðɪs lænd," hi bɛloʊɾ ət ðə mɛn ətɑp ðə wɔl, mænɪdʒɪŋ fɔɹmæləɾi ət ðə tɑp ə hɪz lʌŋz, "bʌt wəɹ mɪɹli pæsɪŋ θɹu, ən wi kʌm fəɹ tʃɹeɪd, nɑt tʃɹʌbəl; tə baɪ ɡɹeɪn ən ʌðɝ nidfəl θɪŋz, nɑt tə faɪt. aɪ hæv ði ɑnɝ tə ənaʊns bɹəleɪn sɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ pɹən, fɝst ə min, blɛsɪɾ ə ðə laɪt, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə weɪvz, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs pɹən, kʌm tə spik wɪð ðə lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi ʌv ðɪs lænd. aɪ hæv ði ɑnɝ tə ənaʊns pɛɹɪn tæʃɪɹ eɪbɑɹə. . . ." hi tɔst ɪn lɔɹɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz fəɹ pɛɹɪn, ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ taɪɾəlz ðət pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ mɔɹ ɹaɪt tə ən hæd nɛvɝ hɝd bɪfɔɹ, ðən wɛn ɑn fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɡɪvɪŋ itʃ ðə fʊl ɑnɝɪfɪk ən æɾɪŋ əɹ ədʒɑ, əz wɛl. ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɪmpɹɛsɪv ɹəsaɪɾəl. wən i fɛl saɪlənt, ðəɹ wɑz . . . saɪləns. ɪn ðə kɹɛnəleɪʃənz əbʌv, dɝɾi-feɪst mɛn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd blik lʊks ən fɪɹs wɪspɝz, ʃɪftɪŋ kɹɔsboʊz ən pɑlɹmz nɝvəsli. oʊnli ə fju wɔɹ hɛlməts əɹ ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝ. moʊst wɝ ɪn ɹʌf koʊts, bʌɾ ɑn wʌn mæn pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i sɔ wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn sɪlk ʌndɝ ə leɪɝ ʌv ɡɹaɪm. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə tɛl, wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ keɪk dɝt. ivən ɪz ɪɹz kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ. "haʊ də wi noʊ jəɹ əlaɪv?" ə hɔɹs vɔɪs ʃaʊɾəd daʊn ət læst.

Near the foot of the bridge, Gallenne drew up. The closed gates, covered with black iron straps a foot wide, would have forced a pause anyway. "We have heard of the troubles plaguing this land," he bellowed at the men atop the wall, managing formality at the top of his lungs, "but we are merely passing through, and we come for trade, not trouble; to buy grain and other needful things, not to fight. I have the honor to announce Berelain sur Paendrag Paeron, First of Mayene, Blessed of the Light, Defender of the Waves, High Seat of House Paeron, come to speak with the lord or lady of this land. I have the honor to announce Perrin t'Bashere Aybara. . . ." He tossed in Lord of the Two Rivers for Perrin, and several other titles that Perrin had no more right to and had never heard before, then went on for the Aes Sedai, giving each the full honorific and adding her Ajah, as well. It was a very impressive recital. When he fell silent, there was . . . silence. In the crenelations above, dirty-faced men exchanged bleak looks and fierce whispers, shifting crossbows and polearms nervously. Only a few wore helmets or any sort of armor. Most were in rough coats, but on one man Perrin thought he saw what might have been silk under a layer of grime. It was hard to tell, with so much caked dirt. Even his ears could not make out what they were saying. "How do we know you're alive?" a hoarse voice shouted down at last.

bɹəleɪn blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt noʊ wʌn læft. ɪt wɑz ful tɔk, jɛt pɛɹɪn θɔt ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk ɹɪli wɑz stændɪŋ stɪf. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz vɛɹi ɹɔŋ, hɪɹ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sim nɑt tə sɛns ɪt. ðən əɡɛn, ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd haɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðoʊz smuð mæsks ə kul sɝɛnəɾi.

Berelain blinked in surprise, but no one laughed. It was fool talk, yet Perrin thought the hair on the back of his neck really was standing stiff. Something was very wrong, here. The Aes Sedai seemed not to sense it. Then again, Aes Sedai could hide anything behind those smooth masks of cool serenity.

ðə bidz ɪn ənʊɹəz θɪn bɹeɪdz klɪk feɪnli əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. mɑsʊɝi ɹæn ən aɪsi ɡeɪz əlɔŋ ðə mɛn ɑn ðə wɔl.

The beads in Annoura's thin braids clicked faintly as she shook her head. Masuri ran an icy gaze along the men on the wall.

"ɪf aɪ mʌs pɹuv aɪm əlaɪv, jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt," siɑnɪɾ ənaʊns laʊdli ɪn kɹɪsp kɛɹhinɪn æksɛns, ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ hiɾəd ðən əɹ feɪs sədʒɛstəd. "ɪf jə kəntɪnju tə pɔɪn ðət kɹɔsboʊ ət mi, jəl ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪɾ ivən mɔɹ." sɛvɹəl ə ðə mɛn heɪstəli ɹeɪz ðɛɹ kɹɔsboʊz tə pɔɪn ət ðə skaɪ. nɑɾ ɔl, ðoʊ. mɔɹ wɪspɝz ɹʌsəld əlɔŋ ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, bʌt sʌmwʌn mʌst əv ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɛɛs sədaɪ.

"If I must prove I am alive, you will regret it," Seonid announced loudly in crisp Cairhienin accents, a little more heated than her face suggested. "If you continue to point that crossbow at me, you will regret it even more." Several of the men hastily raised their crossbows to point at the sky. Not all, though. More whispers rustled along the top of the wall, but someone must have recognized Aes Sedai.

ət læst, ðə ɡeɪts skwild oʊpən ɑn mæsɪv ɹʌsti hɪnʒɪz. ə ɡæɡɪŋ stɛntʃ swɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn, ðə stɪŋk pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn smɛlɪŋ, oʊnli stʃɹɔŋɝ. oʊl dɝɾ ən oʊl swɛt, dəkeɪɪŋ mɪɾənz ən tʃeɪmbɝ pɑts tu lɔŋ ʌnɪmptaɪd. pɛɹɪnz ɪɹz tʃɹaɪd tə laɪ bæk. ɡælɛn hæf-lɪftəɾ ɪz ɹɛd hɛlməɾ əz ɪf tə ɹipleɪs ɪɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd bɪfɔɹ ɝdʒɪŋ ɪz dʌn θɹu ðə ɡeɪts. pɛɹɪn buɾɪd steɪɝ tə fɑloʊ, izɪŋ ɪz æks ɪn ɪts bɛlt lup. dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə ɡeɪt, ə fɪlθi mæn ɪn ə tɔɹn koʊt poʊk pɛɹɪnz lɛɡ wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ, ðən dɑɹɾɪd bæk wən steɪɝ snæpt ət hɪm. ðə fɛloʊ hæd bɪn fæt, wʌns, bʌɾ ɪz koʊt sæɡd ən ɪz skɪn hʌŋ lus. "dʒʌst wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ," hi mʌɾɝd, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz saɪɾ æbsənli. "maɪ lɔɹd," hi æɾəd, ə tɪk leɪt. hɪz aɪz sim tə foʊkəs ɑn pɛɹɪnz feɪs fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ən ɪz skɹætʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz fɹoʊz.

At last, the gates squealed open on massive rusty hinges. A gagging stench swept out of the town, the stink Perrin had been smelling, only stronger. Old dirt and old sweat, decaying middens and chamber pots too long unemptied. Perrin's ears tried to lie back. Gallenne half-lifted his red helmet as if to replace it on his head before urging his dun through the gates. Perrin booted Stayer to follow, easing his axe in its belt loop. Just inside the gate, a filthy man in a torn coat poked Perrin's leg with a finger, then darted back when Stayer snapped at him. The fellow had been fat, once, but his coat sagged and his skin hung loose. "Just wanted to be sure," he muttered, scratching his side absently. "My Lord," he added, a tick late. His eyes seemed to focus on Perrin's face for the first time, and his scratching fingers froze.

ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ aɪz wɝ nɑɾ ə kɑmən saɪt, æftɝ ɔl.

Golden yellow eyes were not a common sight, after all.

"du jə si mɛni dɛd mɛn wɔkɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn æskt ɹaɪli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ə dʒoʊk ʌv ɪt, əz i pæɾəd ðə beɪz nɛk. ə tʃɹeɪnd wɔɹhɔɹs wɑntəd tə bi ɹɪwɔɹɾɪd fəɹ pɹətɛktɪŋ ɪz ɹaɪɾɝ. ðə fɛloʊ flɪntʃt əz ɪf ðə hɔɹs hæd bɛɹd tiθ əɾ ɪm əɡɛn; hɪz maʊθ twɪtʃt ɪndə ə ɹɪktəs smaɪl, ən i ɛdʒ saɪdweɪz. əntɪl i bʌmp sɑlədli ɪndə bɹəleɪnz mɛɹ. ɡælɛn wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ, stɪl lʊkɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə dɑn ɪz hɛlmət, hɪz wʌn aɪ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ sɪks weɪz ət wʌns.

"Do you see many dead men walking?" Perrin asked wryly, trying to make a joke of it, as he patted the bay's neck. A trained warhorse wanted to be rewarded for protecting his rider. The fellow flinched as if the horse had bared teeth at him again; his mouth twitched into a rictus smile, and he edged sideways. Until he bumped solidly into Berelain's mare. Gallenne was right behind her, still looking ready to don his helmet, his one eye trying to watch six ways at once.

"wɛɹ kən aɪ faɪn jəɹ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi?" ʃi dɪmændəɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. min wɑz ə smɔl neɪʃən, bʌt bɹəleɪn wɑz ʌnəkʌstəm tə biɪŋ ɪɡnɔɹd. "ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls simz tə hæv ɡɔn mjut, bʌɾ aɪ hɝd jə juz jəɹ tʌŋ. wɛl, mæn? spik ʌp." ðə fɛloʊ stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɝ, lɪkɪŋ ɪz lɪps. "lɔɹd kaʊlɪn. . . .

"Where can I find your lord or lady?" she demanded impatiently. Mayene was a small nation, but Berelain was unaccustomed to being ignored. "Everyone else seems to have gone mute, but I heard you use your tongue. Well, man? Speak up." The fellow stared up at her, licking his lips. "Lord Cowlin. . . .

lɔɹd kaʊlɪn ɪz . . . əweɪ. maɪ leɪɾi." hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn, ðən flɪkɝɾ əweɪ. "ðə ɡɹeɪn mɝtʃəns. . . . ðəɹ u jə wɑnt. ðeɪ kən ɔlweɪz bi faʊn ət ðə ɡoʊldən bɑɹdʒ. ðət weɪ." hi θɹʌst aʊɾ ə hæn pɔɪntɪŋ veɪɡli dipɝ ɪndə ðə taʊn, ðən sʌɾənli skɹæmbəld əweɪ, lʊkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əɾ əm əz ðoʊ fɪɹfəl ə pɝsut.

Lord Cowlin is . . . away. My Lady." His eyes darted toward Perrin, then flickered away. "The grain merchants. . . . They're who you want. They can always be found at the Golden Barge. That way." He thrust out a hand pointing vaguely deeper into the town, then suddenly scrambled away, looking back over his shoulder at them as though fearful of pursuit.

"aɪ θɪŋk wi ʃəd faɪn sʌmwɛɹ ɛls," pɛɹɪn sɛd. ðət fɛloʊ hæd bɪn əfɹeɪɾ ə mɔɹ ðən jɛloʊ aɪz. ðɪs pleɪs fɛlt . . . əskju.

"I think we should find somewhere else," Perrin said. That fellow had been afraid of more than yellow eyes. This place felt . . . askew.

"wi ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪɹ, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊwɛɹ ɛls," bɹəleɪn ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə vɛɹi pɹæktəkəl vɔɪs. ɪn ɔl ðət stɪŋk, hi kəd nɑt kætʃ əɹ sɛnt; hi wəɾ əv tə ɡoʊ baɪ wʌɾ i hɝɾ ən sɔ, ən əɹ feɪs wɑz kɑm ɪnʌf fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. "aɪv bɪn ɪn taʊnz ðət smɛld wɝs ðən ðɪs, pɛɹɪn. aɪm ʃʊɹ aɪ hæv.

"We are already here, and there is nowhere else," Berelain replied in a very practical voice. In all that stink, he could not catch her scent; he would have to go by what he heard and saw, and her face was calm enough for an Aes Sedai. "I've been in towns that smelled worse than this, Perrin. I'm sure I have.

ən ɪf ðɪs lɔɹd kaʊlɪn ɪz ɡɔn, ɪt woʊn bi ðə fɝs taɪm aɪv dɛlt wɪð mɝtʃəns. jə doʊn ɹɪli bɪliv ðeɪv sin ðə dɛd wɔkɪŋ, də ju?"

And if this Lord Cowlin is gone, it won't be the first time I've dealt with merchants. You don't really believe they've seen the dead walking, do you?"

wʌt wɑz ə mæn tə seɪ tə ðət wɪθaʊt saʊndɪŋ ə pjʊɹ wʊl hɛd? ɪn ɛni keɪs, ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi kɹaʊɾɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɪn ɛni niɾ ɝeɪ, naʊ. wɪntɝ ən ælhæɹə hil siɑnɪd laɪk mɪsmætʃt ɡɑɹd dɑɡz, ðə wʌn fɛɹ, ði ʌðɝ dɑɹk, ən boʊθ ɹɛɾi tə ɹɪp aʊt θɹoʊts ət ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ. ðeɪ sɝɾənli hæd ðə fil ə soʊ hæbɝ. kɝklɪn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd mɑsʊɝi, lʊkt ənwɪlɪŋ tə weɪt fəɹ ðəɾ aɪ tə blɪŋk; hɪz hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. kaɪɹən hæɾ ə hæn tə hɪz noʊz, ən ə ɡlɛɹ ɪn ɪz aɪ ðət sɛd sʌmwʌn wɑz gɑnə peɪ fəɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪm smɛl ðɪs. mɛdɔɹ ən lɑɾən lʊkt ɪl, tu, bʌt beɪlwɝ mɪɹli pɪɹɾ əbaʊt, tɪltɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ðən dʒɹu ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm ɔf ɪndə ə nɛɹoʊ saɪd stʃɹit liɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. əz bɹəleɪn sɛd, ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi.

What was a man to say to that without sounding a pure wool head? In any case, the others were already crowding through the gates, though not in any neat array, now. Wynter and Alharra heeled Seonid like mismatched guard dogs, the one fair, the other dark, and both ready to rip out throats at the blink of an eye. They certainly had the feel of So Habor. Kirklin, riding beside Masuri, looked unwilling to wait for that eye to blink; his hand rested on the hilt of his sword. Kireyin had a hand to his nose, and a glare in his eye that said someone was going to pay for making him smell this. Medore and Latian looked ill, too, but Balwer merely peered about, tilting his head, then drew the pair of them off into a narrow side street leading north. As Berelain said, they were there already.

ðə kʌlɝfəl bænɝz lʊk dɪsaɪɾədli aʊɾ ə pleɪs əz pɛɹɪn ɹoʊd θɹu ðə kɹæmpt waɪndɪŋ stʃɹits ə ðə taʊn. səm ə ðə stʃɹits wɝ æktʃəli  kwaɪt waɪd fəɹ ðə saɪz ə soʊ hæbɝ, bʌt ðeɪ fɛl kloʊs, əz ɪf ðə stoʊn bɪldɪŋz ɑn iðɝ saɪd sʌmhaʊ lum haɪɝ ðən ðɛɹ tu əɹ θɹi stɔɹiz ən wɝ əbaʊt tə tɑpəl ɑn ɪz hɛd, tə but. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən meɪd ðə stʃɹits sim dɪm, tu. ɪt hæd tə bi ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. ðə skaɪ wɑz nɑt ðət ɡɹeɪ. pipəl fɪl ðə dɝɾi stoʊn peɪvɪŋ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə əkaʊn fəɹ ɔl ðə fɑɹmz ɪn ði ɛɹiə biɪŋ əbændənd, ən ɛvɹiwʌn skɝid, hɛdz daʊn. nɑt hɝiɪŋ təwɔɹd sʌmθɪŋ; hɝiɪŋ əweɪ. noʊ wʌn lʊkt əɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls. wɪð ə ɹɪvɝ pɹæktəkli ɑn ðɛɹ dɔɹstɛps, ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə wɑʃ, tu. hi dɪd nɑt si ə feɪs wɪθaʊɾ ə koʊɾɪŋ ʌv ɡɹaɪm əɹ ə ɡɑɹmən ðət dɪd nɑt lʊk tə hæv bɪn wɔɹn fəɹ ə wik, ən hɑɹd wɝk ɪn mʌk wɪð ɪt. ðə stɪŋk oʊnli wɝsən ðə dipɝ ɪndə ðə taʊn ðeɪ ɹoʊd. hi səpoʊz jə kəd ɡɛt juz tə ɛniθɪŋ, ɪn taɪm. wɝst ʌv ɔl wɑz ðə kwaɪət, ðoʊ. vɪlədʒəz wɝ kwaɪət səmtaɪmz, ɪf nɑt soʊ stɪl əz ðə wʊdz, bʌɾ ə taʊn ɔlweɪz hɛld ə feɪn mɝmɝ, ðə saʊn ə ʃɑpkipɝz bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ ən pipəl ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ lɪvz. soʊ hæbɝ dɪd nɑɾ ivən wɪspɝ. ɪt bɛɹli sim tə bɹið.

The colorful banners looked decidedly out of place as Perrin rode through the cramped winding streets of the town. Some of the streets were actually quite wide for the size of So Habor, but they felt close, as if the stone buildings on either side somehow loomed higher than their two or three stories and were about to topple on his head, to boot. Imagination made the streets seem dim, too. It had to be imagination. The sky was not that gray. People filled the dirty stone paving, but not enough to account for all the farms in the area being abandoned, and everyone scurried, heads down. Not hurrying toward something; hurrying away. No one looked at anyone else. With a river practically on their doorsteps, they had forgotten how to wash, too. He did not see a face without a coating of grime or a garment that did not look to have been worn for a week, and hard work in muck with it. The stink only worsened the deeper into the town they rode. He supposed you could get used to anything, in time. Worst of all was the quiet, though. Villages were quiet sometimes, if not so still as the woods, but a town always held a faint murmur, the sound of shopkeepers bargaining and people going about their lives. So Habor did not even whisper. It barely seemed to breathe.

ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ dɝɛkʃənz wɑz dɪfəkəlt, sɪns moʊs pipəl dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ ɪf spoʊkən tə, bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə pɹɑspɝəs-əpɪɹɪŋ ɪn, θɹi stɔɹiz ə nitli dʒɹɛst ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ʌndɝ ə sleɪt ɹuf, wɪð ə saɪn hæŋɪŋ aʊt fɹʌn ənaʊnsɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən bɑɹdʒ. ðə saɪn ivən hæɾ ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɡɪlt ɑn ðə lɛɾɝɪŋ, ən ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪn maʊndɪd haɪ ɪn ðə bɑɹdʒ ən ənkʌvɝɾ əz ɪt nɛvɝ wəd bi fəɹ ʃɪpɪŋ. noʊ ɡɹumz əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə steɪbliɑɹd bɪsaɪd ði ɪn, soʊ ðə bænɝmɪn hæd tə sɝv əz hɔɹs hoʊldɝz, ə tæsk ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk əm hæpi. tɑd pʊt soʊ mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən ɪndə piɹɪŋ ət ðə floʊ ʌv dɝɾi pipəl ðət skɝid baɪ ən fɑndəlɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz ʃɔɹt-sɔɹd ðət steɪɝ vɛɹi nɪɹli ɡɑɾ ə kʌpəl ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz wən i tʊk ðə stæljənz ɹeɪnz. ðə minɝ ən ðə ɡildænɪn sim tə bi wɪʃɪŋ ðeɪ hæd lænsɪz ɹæðɝ ðən bænɝz. flæn dʒʌs lʊkt waɪld-aɪd. ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn, ðə laɪt dɪd sim . . . ʃæɾoʊi. ɡoʊɪŋ ɪnsaɪd dɪd nɑt meɪk θɪŋz ɛni bɛɾɝ.

Getting better directions was difficult, since most people darted away if spoken to, but eventually they dismounted in front of a prosperous-appearing inn, three stories of neatly dressed gray stone under a slate roof, with a sign hanging out front announcing the Golden Barge. The sign even had a touch of gilt on the lettering, and on the grain mounded high in the barge and uncovered as it never would be for shipping. No grooms appeared from the stableyard beside the inn, so the bannermen had to serve as horse holders, a task that did not make them happy. Tod put so much attention into peering at the flow of dirty people that scurried by and fondling the hilt of his short-sword that Stayer very nearly got a couple of his fingers when he took the stallion's reins. The Mayener and the Ghealdanin seemed to be wishing they had lances rather than banners. Flann just looked wild-eyed. In spite of the morning sun, the light did seem . . . shadowy. Going inside did not make things any better.

ət fɝst ɡlæns, ðə kɑmən ɹum bɔɹ aʊt ði ɪnz pɹɑspɛɹəɾi, wɪð pɑlɪʃt ɹaʊn teɪbəlz ən pɹɑpɝ tʃɛɹz ɪnstɛɾ ə bɛntʃɪz, stændɪŋ bɪniθ ə haɪ, staʊt-bim silɪŋ. ðə wɔlz wɝ peɪntəd wɪð filz ə bɑɹli ən oʊts ən mɪlət, ɹaɪpənɪŋ ʌndɝ ə bɹaɪt sʌn, ən ə kʌlɝfli peɪntəd klɑk stʊɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹv mæntəl əbʌv ə waɪd faɪɝpleɪs ʌv waɪt stoʊn. ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɑz koʊld, ðoʊ, ði ɛɹ nɪɹli əz aɪsi əz aʊtsaɪd. ðə klɑk hæd ɹʌn daʊn ən ðə pɑlɪʃ dʌld. dʌs leɪ ɑn ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ði oʊnli pipəl ɪn ðə ɹum wɝ sɪks mɛn ən faɪv wɪmən hʌɾəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ dʒɹɪŋks ɝaʊn ən oʊvəl teɪbəl, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst, ðət stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flɔɹ. wʌn ə ðə mɛn lɛp tə hɪz fit wɪð ən oʊθ, feɪs pælɪŋ ʌndɝniθ ðə dɝt, wən pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɛntɝd. ə plʌmp wʊmən wɪð læŋk ɡɹisi hɛɹ ʃʌvd əɹ pjuɾɝ kʌp tə hɝ maʊθ ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɡʌlp soʊ fæs ðət waɪn spɪld oʊvɝ əɹ tʃɪn. meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɪz aɪz. meɪbi.

At first glance, the common room bore out the inn's prosperity, with polished round tables and proper chairs instead of benches, standing beneath a high, stout-beamed ceiling. The walls were painted with fields of barley and oats and millet, ripening under a bright sun, and a colorfully painted clock stood on the carved mantel above a wide fireplace of white stone. The fireplace was cold, though, the air nearly as icy as outside. The clock had run down and the polish dulled. Dust lay on everything. The only people in the room were six men and five women huddling over their drinks around an oval table, larger than the rest, that stood in the middle of the floor. One of the men leaped to his feet with an oath, face paling underneath the dirt, when Perrin and the others entered. A plump woman with lank greasy hair shoved her pewter cup to her mouth and tried to gulp so fast that wine spilled over her chin. Maybe it was his eyes. Maybe.

"wʌt hæpən ɪn ðɪs taʊn?" ənʊɹə sɛd fɝmli, tɔsɪŋ bæk əɹ kloʊk əz ðoʊ ə faɪɝ bleɪzd ɑn ðə hɑɹθ. ðə kɑm ɡeɪz ʃi ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə pipəl ət ðə teɪbəl fɹoʊz ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm.

"What happened in this town?" Annoura said firmly, tossing back her cloak as though a fire blazed on the hearth. The calm gaze she ran across the people at the table froze every one of them.

əbɹʌpli pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðət niðɝ mɑsʊɝi nɔɹ siɑnɪd hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɪnsaɪd. hi daʊɾɪd vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðət ðeɪ wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹit wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. wʌt ðeɪ ən ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ duɪŋ wɑz ɛni mænz ɡɛs.

Abruptly Perrin realized that neither Masuri nor Seonid had followed him inside. He doubted very much that they were waiting in the street with the horses. What they and their Warders were doing was any man's guess.

ðə mæn u hæd dʒʌmpt ʌp tʌɡd əɾ ɪz koʊt kɑlɝ wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. ðə koʊt hæd bɪn faɪn blu wʊl wʌns, wɪð ə ɹoʊ ʌv ɡɪldɪd bʌɾənz tə hɪz nɛk, bʌɾ i əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn spɪlɪŋ fud daʊn ðə fɹʌn ʌv ɪt fəɹ səm taɪm. meɪbi mɔɹ ðən hæd ɡɔn ɪndə hɪm. hi wɑz ənʌðɝ huz skɪn hʌŋ slæk.

The man who had jumped up tugged at his coat collar with a finger. The coat had been fine blue wool once, with a row of gilded buttons to his neck, but he appeared to have been spilling food down the front of it for some time. Maybe more than had gone into him. He was another whose skin hung slack.

"eɪtʃ-hæpənd, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" hi stæmɝd.

"H-happened, Aes Sedai?" he stammered.

"bi kwaɪət, mɪkəl!" ə hæɡɝd wʊmən sɛd kwɪkli. hɝ dɑɹk dʒɹɛs wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk ən əlɔŋ ðə slivz, bʌt dɝt meɪd ðə kʌlɝz ənsɝɾən. hɝ aɪz wɝ sʌŋkən pɪts. "wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk sʌmθɪŋ hæpənd, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ənʊɹə wəɾ əv kəntɪnjud, bʌt bɹəleɪn stɛpt ɪn əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn. "wi ɑɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪn mɝtʃəns." ənʊɹəz ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt wɪð ən ɑɾəbəl klɪk.

"Be quiet, Mycal!" a haggard woman said quickly. Her dark dress was embroidered on the high neck and along the sleeves, but dirt made the colors uncertain. Her eyes were sunken pits. "What makes you think something happened, Aes Sedai?" Annoura would have continued, but Berelain stepped in as the Aes Sedai opened her mouth again. "We are looking for the grain merchants." Annoura's expression never changed, but her mouth snapped shut with an audible click.

lɔŋ lʊks pæs bɪtwin ðə pipəl ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. ðə hæɡɝd wʊmən stʌɾid ənʊɹə fəɹ ə moʊmənt, kwɪkli pæsɪŋ ɑn tə bɹəleɪn ən ɑbviəsli teɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə sɪlks ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps. ən ðə daɪədɛm. ʃi spɹɛɾ əɹ skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi. "wi ɑɹ ðə mɝtʃəns ɡɪld ə soʊ hæbɝ, maɪ leɪɾi. wʌts lɛft ə  -  " bɹeɪkɪŋ ɔf, ʃi tʊk ə dip, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. "aɪ æm ɹæhimə ɑɹnən, maɪ leɪɾi. haʊ meɪ wi sɝv ju?"

Long looks passed between the people around the table. The haggard woman studied Annoura for a moment, quickly passing on to Berelain and obviously taking in the silks and firedrops. And the diadem. She spread her skirts in a curtsy. "We are the merchant's guild of So Habor, my Lady. What's left of  -  " Breaking off, she took a deep, shuddering breath. "I am Rahema Arnon, my Lady. How may we serve you?"

ðə mɝtʃəns sim tə bɹaɪɾən ə lɪɾəl ɑn lɝnɪŋ ðət ðɛɹ vɪzəɾɝz hæd kʌm fəɹ ɡɹeɪn ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðət ðeɪ kəd səplaɪ, ɔɪl fəɹ læmps ən kʊkɪŋ, binz ən niɾəlz ən hɔɹsʃu neɪlz, klɔθ ən kændəlz ən ə dʌzən θɪŋz mɔɹ ðət ðə kæmp niɾəd. ət list, ðeɪ ɡɹu ə lɪɾəl lɛs fɪɹfəl.

The merchants seemed to brighten a little on learning that their visitors had come for grain and other things that they could supply, oil for lamps and cooking, beans and needles and horseshoe nails, cloth and candles and a dozen things more that the camp needed. At least, they grew a little less fearful.

ɛni ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɝtʃən hɪɹɪŋ ðə lɪs bɹəleɪn ɡeɪv wʊɾə bɪn hɑɹd-pɹɛs nɑt tə smaɪl ɡɹiɾəli, bʌt ðɪs lɑt. . . .

Any ordinary merchant hearing the list Berelain gave would have been hard-pressed not to smile greedily, but this lot. . . .

mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ ði ɪnkipɝ tə bɹɪŋ waɪn  -  "ðə bɛst waɪn; kwɪkli, naʊ; kwɪkli"  -  bʌt wən ə lɔŋ-noʊzd wʊmən stʌk əɹ hɛd hɛzɪɾəntli ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum, mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən hæd tə ɹʌʃ oʊvɝ ən kætʃ əɹ sɔɪl sliv tə kip əɹ fɹəm vænɪʃɪŋ əɡɛn. ðə fɛloʊ ɪn ðə fud-steɪn koʊt kɔl fəɹ sʌmwʌn neɪm spɝəl tə bɹɪŋ ðə sæmpəl dʒɑɹz, bʌɾ æftɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ θɹi taɪmz wɪð noʊ ɹɪspɑns, hi ɡeɪv ə nɝvəs læf ən dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ə bæk ɹum tə ɹɪtɝn ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, hɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn θɹi lɑɹdʒ səlɪnʒɹɪkəl wʊɾən kənteɪnɝz ðəɾ i sæɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, stɪl læfɪŋ nɝvəsli. ði ʌðɝz wɔɹ ə kəlɛkʃən ə twɪtʃɪŋ smaɪlz əz ðeɪ baʊɾ ən kɝtsid bɹəleɪn tə ə siɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ði oʊvəl teɪbəl, ɡɹisi-feɪs mɛn ən wɪmən skɹætʃɪŋ ət ðɛmsɛlvz wɪθaʊɾ əpɪɹɪŋ tə noʊɾəs wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. pɛɹɪn tʌkt ɪz ɡɔnləts bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt ən stʊɾ əɡɛnst ə peɪntəd wɔl, wɑtʃɪŋ. ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɹid tə liv ðə bɑɹɡɪnɪŋ tə bɹəleɪn. ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt, ɹɪlʌktənli, ðəɾ i nu mɔɹ ə hɔɹsflɛʃ ðən ʃi, bʌt ʃi hæd nəɡoʊʃieɪɾəd tʃɹiɾiz kʌvɝɪŋ ðə seɪl ə jɪɹz' wɝθ ə ði ɔɪlfɪʃ hɑɹvəst. ənʊɹə hæd smaɪl θɪnli ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən ðəɾ ə dʒʌmpt-ʌp kʌntʃɹi læd maɪt teɪk ə hænd. ʃi dɪd nɑt kɔl ɪm ðæt  -  ʃi kəd "maɪ lɔɹd" hɪm əz smuðli əz mɑsʊɝi əɹ siɑnɪd  -  jɛɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ʃi θɔt səm θɪŋz klɪɹli əbʌv ɪz əbɪləɾi. ʃi wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ naʊ, stændɪŋ bɪhaɪn bɹəleɪn ən stʌɾiɪŋ ðə mɝtʃəns əz ɪf tə mɛmɝaɪz ðɛɹ feɪsəz.

Mistress Arnon shouted for the innkeeper to bring wine  -  "the best wine; quickly, now; quickly"  -  but when a long-nosed woman stuck her head hesitantly into the common room, Mistress Arnon had to rush over and catch her soiled sleeve to keep her from vanishing again. The fellow in the food-stained coat called for someone named Speral to bring the sample jars, but after shouting three times with no response, he gave a nervous laugh and darted into a back room to return a moment later, his arms around three large cylindrical wooden containers that he sat on the table, still laughing nervously. The others wore a collection of twitching smiles as they bowed and curtsied Berelain to a seat at the head of the oval table, greasy-faced men and women scratching at themselves without appearing to notice what they were doing. Perrin tucked his gauntlets behind his belt and stood against a painted wall, watching. They had agreed to leave the bargaining to Berelain. She was willing to admit, reluctantly, that he knew more of horseflesh than she, but she had negotiated treaties covering the sale of years' worth of the oilfish harvest. Annoura had smiled thinly at the suggestion that a jumped-up country lad might take a hand. She did not call him that  -  she could "my Lord" him as smoothly as Masuri or Seonid  -  yet it was clear she thought some things clearly above his ability. She was not smiling now, standing behind Berelain and studying the merchants as if to memorize their faces.

ði ɪnkipɝ bɹɔt waɪn, ɪn pjuɾɝ kʌps ðət hæd læst sin ə pɑlɪʃɪŋ klɔθ wiks əɡoʊ ɪf nɑt mʌnθs, bʌt pɛɹɪn oʊnli pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz ən swɝld ɪɾ ɪn ðə kʌp. mɪstʃɹəs veɪdɪɹ, ði ɪnkipɝ, hæd dɝɾ ʌndɝ əɹ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ən ɛmbɛɾɪd ɪn əɹ nʌkəlz laɪk pɑɹɾ ə hɝ skɪn. hi noʊɾəst ðət ɡælɛn, stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz bæk tə ði ɑpəzət wɔl ən wʌn hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, oʊnli hɛld ɪz kʌp, tu, ən bɹəleɪn nɛvɝ tʌtʃt hɝz. kaɪɹən snɪft ət hɪz, ðən dʒɹæŋk dipli ən kɔl fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs veɪdɪɹ tə bɹɪŋ ɪm ə pɪtʃɝ.

The innkeeper brought wine, in pewter cups that had last seen a polishing cloth weeks ago if not months, but Perrin only peered into his and swirled it in the cup. Mistress Vadere, the innkeeper, had dirt under her fingernails and embedded in her knuckles like part of her skin. He noticed that Gallenne, standing with his back to the opposite wall and one hand on his sword hilt, only held his cup, too, and Berelain never touched hers. Kireyin sniffed at his, then drank deeply and called for Mistress Vadere to bring him a pitcher.

"θɪn stʌf, tə bi kɔl jəɹ bɛst," hi toʊl ðə wʊmən θɹu hɪz noʊz, ən lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɪt, "bʌɾ ɪt maɪt wɑʃ əweɪ ðə stɪŋk." ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm blæŋkli, ðən fɛtʃt ə tɔl pjuɾɝ pɪtʃɝ tə hɪz teɪbəl wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ə wɝd. kaɪɹən əpɛɹənli tʊk əɹ saɪləns fəɹ ɹɪspɛkt.

"Thin stuff, to be called your best," he told the woman through his nose, and looking down it, "but it might wash away the stink." She stared at him blankly, then fetched a tall pewter pitcher to his table without saying a word. Kireyin apparently took her silence for respect.

mæstɝ kɹɑsɪn, ðə fɛloʊ ɪn ðə fud-steɪn koʊt, ənskɹud ðə tɑps ə ðə wʊɾən kənteɪnɝz ən spɪld aʊt hʌl sæmpəlz ə ðə ɡɹeɪn ðeɪ hæd tə ɔfɝ ɪn paɪlz ɑn ðə teɪbəl, jɛloʊ mɪləɾ ən bɹaʊn oʊts, ðə bɑɹli oʊnli ə lɪɾəl dɑɹkɝ bɹaʊn. ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn noʊ ɹeɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə hɑɹvəst.

Master Crossin, the fellow in the food-stained coat, unscrewed the tops of the wooden containers and spilled out hulled samples of the grain they had to offer in piles on the table, yellow millet and brown oats, the barley only a little darker brown. There would have been no rain before the harvest.

"ðə faɪnəs kwɑləɾi, əz jə kən si," hi sɛd.

"The finest quality, as you can see," he said.

"jɛs, ðə faɪnəst." ðə smaɪl slɪɾ ɔf mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnənz feɪs, ən ʃi dʒɝkt ɪt bæk. "wi sɛl oʊnli ðə faɪnəst."

"Yes, the finest." The smile slid off Mistress Arnon's face, and she jerked it back. "We sell only the finest."

fəɹ pipəl taʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ wɛɹz əz ðə faɪnəst, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə bɑɹɡən vɛɹi hɑɹd. pɛɹɪn hæd wɑtʃt mɛn ən wɪmən bæk hoʊm sɛlɪŋ ðə wʊl klɪp ən ðə təbæk tə mɝtʃəns daʊn fɹəm bɛɹlən, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz dɪspɛɹɪdʒ ðə baɪɝz' ɔfɝz, səmtaɪmz kəmpleɪnɪŋ ðə mɝtʃəns wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɛɡɝ əm wən ðə pɹaɪs wɑz twaɪs wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn ðə jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ əɹ ivən sədʒɛstɪŋ ðeɪ maɪt weɪt tɪl nɛks jɪɹ tə sɛl əɾ ɔl. ɪt wɑz ə dæns əz ɪntʃɹəkəɾ əz ɛni əɾ ə fistdeɪ.

For people touting their wares as the finest, they did not seem to bargain very hard. Perrin had watched men and women back home selling the wool clip and the tabac to merchants down from Baerlon, and they always disparaged the buyers' offers, sometimes complaining the merchants were trying to beggar them when the price was twice what it had been the year before or even suggesting they might wait till next year to sell at all. It was a dance as intricate as any at a feastday.

"aɪ səpoʊz wi maɪt loʊɝ ðə pɹaɪs fɝðɝ fəɹ sətʃ ə lɑɹdʒ kwɑntəɾi," ə bɔldɪŋ mæn toʊl bɹəleɪn, skɹætʃɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɡɹeɪstʃɹik bɪɹd. ɪt wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹt, ən ɡɹisi ɪnʌf tə klɪŋ kloʊs tə hɪz tʃɪn. pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə skɹætʃ ɪz oʊn bɪɹd dʒʌst wɑtʃɪŋ ðə fɛloʊ.

"I suppose we might lower the price further for such a large quantity," a balding man told Berelain, scratching at his graystreaked beard. It was cut short, and greasy enough to cling close to his chin. Perrin wanted to scratch his own beard just watching the fellow.

"ɪts bɪn ə hɑɹd wɪntɝ," ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən mʌɾɝd. oʊnli tu ʌv ði ʌðɝ mɝtʃəns bɑðɝd tə fɹaʊn ət hɝ.

"It's been a hard winter," a round-faced woman muttered. Only two of the other merchants bothered to frown at her.

pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪz waɪnkʌp daʊn ɑn ə nɪɹbaɪ teɪbəl ən wɔkt ʌv$ tə ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum. ənʊɹə ɡeɪv ɪm wʌn ʃɑɹp, wɔɹnɪŋ ɡlæns, bʌt sɛvɹəl ə ðə mɝtʃəns lʊkt əɾ ɪm kjʊɹiəsli. ən kɔʃəsli. ɡælɛn hæd meɪɾ ɪz ɪntʃɹədʌkʃənz ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn, bʌt ðiz foʊk wɝ nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli klɪɹ wɛɹ min wɑz, ɪɡzækli, əɹ haʊ paʊɝfəl, ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz oʊnli mɛnt ɡʊd təbæk, tə ðɛm. tu ɹɪvɝz təbæk wɑz noʊn ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hɪz aɪz maɪɾ əv sɛɾ əm ɹʌnɪŋ. ɛvɹiwʌn fɛl saɪlən əz pɛɹɪn skupt ʌp ə hændfʊl ə mɪlət, ðə taɪni sfɪɹz smuð ən vɪvəd jɛloʊ ɑn ɪz pɑm. ðɪs ɡɹeɪn wɑz ðə fɝs klin θɪŋ i hæd sin ɪn ðə taʊn. lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪn spɪl bæk ɑntu ðə teɪbəl, hi pɪkt ʌp ðə lɪɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə kənteɪnɝz. ðə θɹɛdz kʌɾ ɪndə ðə wʊd wɝ ʃɑɹp ən ənwɹn. ðə lɪd wəd fɪt taɪtli.

Perrin set his winecup down on a nearby table and walked ove$ to the gathering in the middle of the room. Annoura gave him one sharp, warning glance, but several of the merchants looked at him curiously. And cautiously. Gallenne had made his introductions all over again, but these folk were not entirely clear where Mayene was, exactly, or how powerful, and the Two Rivers only meant good tabac, to them. Two Rivers tabac was known everywhere. If not for the presence of an Aes Sedai, his eyes might have set them running. Everyone fell silent as Perrin scooped up a handful of millet, the tiny spheres smooth and vivid yellow on his palm. This grain was the first clean thing he had seen in the town. Letting the grain spill back onto the table, he picked up the lid of one of the containers. The threads cut into the wood were sharp and unworn. The lid would fit tightly.

mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnənz aɪz slɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɪz, ən ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps.

Mistress Arnon's eyes slid away from his, and she licked her lips.

"aɪ wɑnə si ðə ɡɹeɪn ɪn ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz," hi sɛd. hæf ðə pipəl ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl twɪtʃt.

"I want to see the grain in the warehouses," he said. Half the people around the table twitched.

mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, blʌstɝɪŋ. "wi doʊn sɛl wʌt wi doʊn hæv. jə kən wɑtʃ əɹ leɪbɝɝz loʊɾ ɛvɹi sæk ɑn jəɹ kɑɹts, ɪf jə wɪʃ tə spɛn aʊɝz ɪn ðə koʊld." "aɪ wɑz əbaʊt tə sədʒɛst ə vɪzət tə ə wɛɹhaʊs," bɹəleɪn pʊɾ ɪn. ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi dʒɹu hɝ ɹɛd ɡlʌvz fɹəm bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt ən bɪɡæn tʌɡɪŋ əm ɑn. "aɪ wəd nɛvɝ baɪ ɡɹeɪn wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ðə wɛɹhaʊs." mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən sæɡd. ðə bɔld-hɛɾəd mæn pʊɾ ɪz hɛd daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl. noʊ wʌn sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ, ðoʊ. ðə dɪspɪɹəɾɪd mɝtʃəns dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə fɛtʃ ðɛɹ kloʊks bɪfɔɹ liɾɪŋ əm ɪndə ðə stʃɹit. ðə bɹiz hæd pɪkt ʌp tə ə wɪnd, koʊld əz oʊnli ə leɪt wɪntɝ wɪn kəd bi, wən pipəl wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi θɪŋkɪŋ əhɛd tə spɹɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. ðə hʌntʃ ə ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð koʊld. "kæn wi ɡoʊ naʊ, lɔɹd pɝɹɪnp" flæn æskt æŋkʃəsli wən pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz əpɪɹd. "ðɪs pleɪs meɪks mi wɑn ə bæθ." ənʊɹə ɡeɪv ɪm ə fɹaʊn ɪn pæsɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪm flɪntʃ laɪk wʌn ə ðə mɝtʃəns. flæn tʃɹaɪɾ ə pleɪkeɪɾɪŋ smaɪl ɑn hɝ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə sɪkli ɛfɝt, ən tu leɪt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ əɹ bæk.

Mistress Arnon drew herself up, blustering. "We don't sell what we don't have. You can watch our laborers load every sack on your carts, if you wish to spend hours in the cold." "I was about to suggest a visit to a warehouse," Berelain put in. Rising, she drew her red gloves from behind her belt and began tugging them on. "I would never buy grain without seeing the warehouse." Mistress Arnon sagged. The bald-headed man put his head down on the table. No one said anything, though. The dispirited merchants did not bother to fetch their cloaks before leading them into the street. The breeze had picked up to a wind, cold as only a late winter wind could be, when people were already thinking ahead to spring, but they did not seem to notice. The hunch of their shoulders had nothing to do with cold. "Can we go now, Lord PerrinP" Flann asked anxiously when Perrin and the others appeared. "This place makes me want a bath." Annoura gave him a frown in passing that made him flinch like one of the merchants. Flann tried a placating smile on her, but it was a sickly effort, and too late for anything but her back.

"æz sun əz aɪ kən ɝeɪnʒ ɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd. ðə mɝtʃəns wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi skɝiɪŋ daʊn ðə stʃɹit, hɛdz daʊn ən nɑt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniwʌn. bɹəleɪn ən ənʊɹə mænədʒ tə fɑloʊ wɪθaʊɾ əpɪɹɪŋ tə ɹʌʃ, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ, wʌn əz kəmpoʊzd əz ði ʌðɝ, tu faɪn leɪɾiz aʊt fəɹ ə stʃɹoʊl ən nɛvɝ maɪn ðə fɪlθ ʌndɝfʊt, əɹ ðə stɪŋk ɪn ði ɛɹ, əɹ ðə dɝɾi pipəl u stɑɹɾəd ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm ən səmtaɪmz ɔl bʌt ɹæn əweɪ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd. ɡælɛn hæd faɪnəli dɑn ɪz hɛlmət, ən oʊpənli hɛld ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt wɪð boʊθ hænz, ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɔ. kaɪɹən wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ɪz hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, hɪz ʌðɝ hæn ɑkjəpaɪd wɪð ɪz waɪnkʌp. kəntɛmptʃwəsli aɪɪŋ ðə ɡɹaɪmi-feɪs foʊk u hɝid baɪ, hi snɪft ət ðə waɪn əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə poʊmændɝ tə faɪɾ ɔf ðə stɛntʃ ə ðə taʊn. ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz wɝ loʊkeɪɾəd ɑn ə stoʊn-peɪv stʃɹit bɛɹli waɪɾɝ ðən ə wæɡən, bɪtwin ðə taʊnz tu wɔlz. ðə smɛl wɑz bɛɾɝ ðɛɹ, kloʊs tə ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt ðə wɪnbloʊn stʃɹit wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ivən ə stʃɹeɪ dɔɡ tə bi sin. dɑɡz dɪsəpɪɹd wən ə taʊn ɡɹu hʌŋɡɹi, bʌt waɪ wəɾ ə taʊn wɪð ɪnʌf ɡɹeɪn tə sɛl bi hʌŋɡɹi? pɛɹɪn pɔɪntəd tə ə tu-stɔɹi wɛɹhaʊs tʃoʊzən ət ɹændəm, noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ, ə wɪndoʊləs stoʊn bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə waɪd pɛɹ ʌv wʊɾən dɔɹz hɛld ʃʌt baɪ ə wʊɾən bɑɹ ðət cʊɾə dʌn fəɹ ə silɪŋ bim ət ðə ɡoʊldən bɑɹdʒ.

"As soon as I can arrange it," Perrin said. The merchants were already scurrying down the street, heads down and not looking at anyone. Berelain and Annoura managed to follow without appearing to rush, gliding along, one as composed as the other, two fine ladies out for a stroll and never mind the filth underfoot, or the stink in the air, or the dirty people who started at the sight of them and sometimes all but ran away as fast as they could. Gallenne had finally donned his helmet, and openly held his sword hilt with both hands, ready to draw. Kireyin was carrying his helmet on his hip, his other hand occupied with his winecup. Contemptuously eyeing the grimy-faced folk who hurried by, he sniffed at the wine as if it were a pomander to fight off the stench of the town. The warehouses were located on a stone-paved street barely wider than a wagon, between the town's two walls. The smell was better there, close to the river, but the windblown street was empty except for Perrin and the others. There was not even a stray dog to be seen. Dogs disappeared when a town grew hungry, but why would a town with enough grain to sell be hungry? Perrin pointed to a two-story warehouse chosen at random, no different from any other, a windowless stone building with a wide pair of wooden doors held shut by a wooden bar that could have done for a ceiling beam at the Golden Barge.

ðə mɝtʃəns sʌɾənli ɹɪkɔl ðət ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə bɹɪŋ mɛn tə lɪf ðə bɑɹz. ðeɪ ɔfɝd tə ɡoʊ bæk fəɹ ðɛm. ðə leɪɾi bɹəleɪn ən ənʊɹə sədaɪ kəd ɹɛst ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝ ət ðə ɡoʊldən bɑɹdʒ waɪl wɝkmɪn wɝ fɛtʃt. ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ mɪstʃɹəs veɪdɪɹ wəd leɪ ə faɪɝ. ðɛɹ tʌŋz wɛn stɪl wən pɛɹɪn pleɪst ɪz hæn bɪniθ ðə θɪk bim ən ʃʌvd ɪɾ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə wʊɾən bɹækəts. ðə θɪŋ wɑz hɛvi, bʌɾ i bækt ʌp wɪð ɪt tə ɡɪv ɪm ɹum tə tɝn ən tɔs ɪt daʊn ɑn ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə kɹæʃ. ðə mɝtʃəns stɛɹd. ðɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ə mæn ɪn ə sɪlk koʊt də ɛniθɪŋ ðət kəd bi kɔld wɝk. kaɪɹən ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz ən tʊk ənʌðɝ snɪf əɾ ɪz waɪn.

The merchants suddenly recalled that they had forgotten to bring men to lift the bars. They offered to go back for them. The Lady Berelain and Annoura Sedai could rest in front of the fire at the Golden Barge while workmen were fetched. They were sure Mistress Vadere would lay a fire. Their tongues went still when Perrin placed his hand beneath the thick beam and shoved it up out of the wooden brackets. The thing was heavy, but he backed up with it to give him room to turn and toss it down on the street with a crash. The merchants stared. This might have been the first time they had ever seen a man in a silk coat do anything that could be called work. Kireyin rolled his eyes and took another sniff at his wine.

"læntɝnz," mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən sɛd wikli. "wil nid læntɝnz, əɹ tɔɹtʃɪz. ɪf. . . . " ə bɔl ə laɪɾ əpɪɹd floʊɾɪŋ əbʌv ənʊɹəz hænd, ɡloʊɪŋ bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ tə kæst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn feɪnt ʃædoʊz ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ ən ðə stoʊn wɔlz. səm ə ðə mɝtʃəns pʊt hænz ʌp tə ʃil ðɛɹ aɪz. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, mæstɝ kɹɑsɪn tʌɡd wʌn ə ðə dɔɹz oʊpən baɪ ən aɪɝn ɹɪŋ.

"Lanterns," Mistress Arnon said weakly. "We'll need lanterns, or torches. If. . . . " A ball of light appeared floating above Annoura's hand, glowing bright enough in the gray morning to cast everyone in faint shadows on the paving and the stone walls. Some of the merchants put hands up to shield their eyes. After a moment, Master Crossin tugged one of the doors open by an iron ring.

ðə smɛl ɪnsaɪd wɑz ðə fəmɪljɝ ʃɑɹp sɛn ə bɑɹli, ɔlmoʊst stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝkʌm ðə stɛntʃ ə ðə taʊn, ən sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ. smɔl dɪm ʃeɪps slʌŋk əweɪ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz əhɛɾ ʌv ənʊɹəz laɪt. hi cʊɾə sin bɛɾɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, əɹ ət lis dipɝ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə ɡloʊɪŋ bɔl kæst ə lɑɹdʒ pul ə laɪt, ən wɔld ɔf wʌt leɪ bɪɑnd. hi smɛl kæt, kloʊsɝ tə fɛɹəl ðən nɑt.

The smell inside was the familiar sharp scent of barley, almost strong enough to overcome the stench of the town, and something more. Small dim shapes slunk away into the shadows ahead of Annoura's light. He could have seen better without it, or at least deeper into the darkness. The glowing ball cast a large pool of light, and walled off what lay beyond. He smelled cat, closer to feral than not.

ən ɹæt, tu. ə sʌɾən skwil ɪn ðə blæk dɛpθs ə ðə wɛɹhaʊs, sʌɾənli kʌɾ ɔf, spoʊk ə kæt miɾɪŋ ɹæt. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz ɹæts ɪn ɡɹeɪn bɑɹnz, ən kæts tə hʌn ðɛm. ɪt wɑz kʌmfɝɾɪŋ, ən nɔɹməl.

And rat, too. A sudden squeal in the black depths of the warehouse, suddenly cut off, spoke of cat meeting rat. There were always rats in grain barns, and cats to hunt them. It was comforting, and normal.

ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə suð ɪz ʌnizinəs. ɔlmoʊst. hi smɛl sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ə smɛl i ʃəd noʊ. ə fɪɹs jaʊl dip ɪn ðə wɛɹhaʊs tɝn tə ɹaɪzɪŋ kɹaɪz ə peɪn ðət daɪɾ əbɹʌpli. əpɛɹənli ðə ɹæts ə soʊ hæbɝ səmtaɪmz hʌntəd bæk. pɛɹɪnz hækəlz stɝɾ əɡɛn, bʌt ʃʊɹli ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ hɪɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn wəd wɑnə spaɪ ɑn. moʊst ɹæts wɝ dʒʌst ɹæts. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə ɡoʊ vɛɹi fɑɹ ɪn. kɔɹs sæks fɪl ðə dɑɹknəs, ɪn haɪ slænt-saɪɾəd stæks ɑn loʊ wʊɾən plætfɔɹmz tə kip ðə sæks ɔf ðə stoʊn flɔɹ. ɹoʊz ən ɹoʊz ə stæks paɪl nɪɹli tə ðə silɪŋ, ən laɪkli ðə seɪm ɑn ðə flɔɹ əbʌv.

Almost enough to soothe his uneasiness. Almost. He smelled something else, a smell he should know. A fierce yowl deep in the warehouse turned to rising cries of pain that died abruptly. Apparently the rats of So Habor sometimes hunted back. Perrin's hackles stirred again, but surely there was nothing here the Dark One would want to spy on. Most rats were just rats. There was no need to go very far in. Coarse sacks filled the darkness, in high slant-sided stacks on low wooden platforms to keep the sacks off the stone floor. Rows and rows of stacks piled nearly to the ceiling, and likely the same on the floor above.

ɪf nɑt, ðɪs bɪldɪŋ stɪl hɛld ɪnʌf ɡɹeɪn tə fiɾ ɪz pipəl fəɹ wiks. wɔkɪŋ tə ðə nɪɹəst stæk, hi dʒɹoʊv ɪz bɛl naɪf ɪndə ə peɪl bɹaʊn sæk ən slaɪs daʊn θɹu ðə tʌf dʒut faɪbɝz. ə flʌɾ ə bɑɹlikɔɹnz spɪld aʊt. ænd, klɪɹ ɪn ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ənʊɹəz bɹɪljən laɪt, ɹɪəlɪŋ blæk spɛks.

If not, this building still held enough grain to feed his people for weeks. Walking to the nearest stack, he drove his belt knife into a pale brown sack and sliced down through the tough jute fibers. A flood of barleycorns spilled out. And, clear in the glow of Annoura's brilliant light, wriggling black specks.

wivəlz, ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni əz ðəɹ wɝ bɑɹlikɔɹnz. ðɛɹ sɛnt wɑz ʃɑɹpɝ ðən ðəɾ ə ðə bɑɹli.

Weevils, almost as many as there were barleycorns. Their scent was sharper than that of the barley.

wivəlz. hi wɪʃt ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz nɛk wəd stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹaɪz. ðə koʊld ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə kɪl wivəlz. ðət wʌn sæk wɑz pɹuf, ən ɪz noʊz nu ðə smɛl ʌv wivəlz, naʊ, bʌɾ i muv tə ənʌðɝ stæk, ðən ənʌðɝ, ən ənʌðɝ, itʃ taɪm slaɪsɪŋ oʊpən wʌn sæk. itʃ ɹilist ə spɪl ə peɪl bɹaʊn bɑɹli ən blæk wivəlz.

Weevils. He wished the hair on his neck would stop trying to rise. The cold should have been enough to kill weevils. That one sack was proof, and his nose knew the smell of weevils, now, but he moved to another stack, then another, and another, each time slicing open one sack. Each released a spill of pale brown barley and black weevils.

ðə mɝtʃəns wɝ stændɪŋ hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, deɪlaɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm, bʌɾ ənʊɹəz laɪt kæs ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɪn ʃɑɹp ɹɪlif. wɝid feɪsəz. dɪspɛɹɪŋ feɪsəz. "wi wəd bi moʊs hæpi tə wɪnoʊ itʃ sæk wi sɛl," mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli. "fɔɹ oʊnli ə slaɪɾ ədɪʃənəl - "

The merchants were standing huddled together in the doorway, daylight behind them, but Annoura's light cast their faces in sharp relief. Worried faces. Despairing faces. "We would be most happy to winnow each sack we sell," Mistress Arnon said unsteadily. "For only a slight additional - "

"fɔɹ hæf ðə læs pɹaɪs aɪ ɔfɝd," bɹəleɪn kʌɾ ɪn ʃɑɹpli. ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ əɹ noʊz ɪn dɪsɡʌst, ʃi muvd əɹ skɝts klɪɹ ə ðə wivəlz skʌɾəlɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹeɪn ɑn ðə flɔɹ. "ju wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ɔl ə ðɛm."

"For half the last price I offered," Berelain cut in sharply. Wrinkling her nose in disgust, she moved her skirts clear of the weevils scuttling among the grain on the floor. "You will never get all of them."

"ænd noʊ mɪlət," pɛɹɪn sɛd ɡɹɪmli. hɪz mɛn niɾəd fud, ən soʊ dɪd ðə soʊlʒɝz, bʌt ðə mɪlət ɡɹeɪnz wɝ hɑɹdli bɪɡɝ ðən ðə wivəlz. wɪnoʊ əz ðeɪ wʊd, hi wəd bɹɪŋ bæk wivəlz ən mɪləɾ ɪn ikwəl weɪt. "wil teɪk ɛkstʃɹə binz ɪnstɛd. bʌt ðeɪ ɡɛt wɪnoʊd, tu." sʌɾənli sʌmwʌn ʃɹikt aʊtsaɪɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit. nɑɾ ə kæɾ əɹ ə ɹæt, bʌɾ ə mæn ɪn tɛɹɝ. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪz i hæd dʒɹɔn ɪz æks əntɪl i faʊn ðə hæft ɪn ɪz hæn əz i pʊʃt θɹu ðə mɝtʃəns ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. ðeɪ hʌɾəld kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ, lɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ lɪps ən nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si hu hæd skɹimd. kaɪɹən wɑz bækt ʌp əɡɛns ðə wɔl ʌv ə wɛɹhaʊs əkɹɔs ðə weɪ, hɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ hɛlmət wɪð ðə waɪt plum laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvmən bɪsaɪɾ ɪz waɪnkʌp. ðə mænz sɔɹd wɑz hæf aʊɾ ə ðə skæbɝd, bʌɾ i sim fɹoʊzən, stɛɹɪŋ wɪð bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz ət ðə wɔl ə ðə bɪldɪŋ pɛɹɪn hæd dʒʌs kʌm aʊɾ ʌv. pɛɹɪn tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, ən i dʒʌmpt.

"And no millet," Perrin said grimly. His men needed food, and so did the soldiers, but the millet grains were hardly bigger than the weevils. Winnow as they would, he would bring back weevils and millet in equal weight. "We'll take extra beans instead. But they get winnowed, too." Suddenly someone shrieked outside in the street. Not a cat or a rat, but a man in terror. Perrin did not even realize he had drawn his axe until he found the haft in his hand as he pushed through the merchants in the doorway. They huddled closer together, licking their lips and not even trying to see who had screamed. Kireyin was backed up against the wall of a warehouse across the way, his shining helmet with the white plume lying on the pavement beside his winecup. The man's sword was half out of the scabbard, but he seemed frozen, staring with bulging eyes at the wall of the building Perrin had just come out of. Perrin touched his arm, and he jumped.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ə mæn," ðə ɡildænɪn sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli. "hi wɑz dʒʌs ðɛɹ. hi lʊkt ət mi, ænd. .

"There was a man," the Ghealdanin said uncertainly. "He was just there. He looked at me, and. .

. ." kaɪɹən skɹʌbd ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs. dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld, swɛt ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. "hi wɔk θɹu ðə wɔl. hi dɪd. jə mʌs bɪliv mi."

. ." Kireyin scrubbed a hand over his face. Despite the cold, sweat glistened on his forehead. "He walked through the wall. He did. You must believe me."

sʌmwʌn moʊnd; wʌn ə ðə mɝtʃəns, pɛɹɪn θɔt. "aɪ sɔ ðə mæn, tu," siɑnɪd sɛd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən ɪt wɑz ɪz tɝn tə ɡɪv ə stɑɹt. hɪz noʊz wɑz jusləs ɪn ðɪs pleɪs! ɡɪvɪŋ ðə wɔl kaɪɹən hæɾ ɪndəkeɪɾəd ə læst ɡlæns, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ɪt wɪð ə pælpəbəl ənwɪlɪŋnɪs.

Someone moaned; one of the merchants, Perrin thought. "I saw the man, too," Seonid said behind him, and it was his turn to give a start. His nose was useless in this place! Giving the wall Kireyin had indicated a last glance, the Aes Sedai stepped away from it with a palpable unwillingness.

hɝ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ tɔl mɛn, taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ, bʌt ðeɪ steɪɾ oʊnli fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ tə ɡeɪn ɹum tə dʒɹɔ ðɛɹ sɔɹdz. ðoʊ wʌt ðə ɡɹɪm-aɪd wɔɹɾɝz wɝ tə faɪɾ ɪf siɑnɪd wɑz sɪɹiəs, pɛɹɪn kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən.

Her Warders were tall men, towering over her, but they stayed only far enough away to gain room to draw their swords. Though what the grim-eyed Warders were to fight if Seonid was serious, Perrin could not imagine.

"aɪ faɪn ɪt dɪfəkəl tə laɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," siɑnɪd sɛd dʒɹaɪli wən i ɪkspɹɛs daʊt, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn kwɪkli bɪkeɪm əz sɪɹiəs əz əɹ feɪs, ən əɹ aɪz wɝ soʊ ɪntɛn ðət ðeɪ əloʊn bɪɡæn tə meɪk pɛɹɪn fil ənizi. "ðə dɛɾ ɑɹ wɔkɪŋ ɪn soʊ hæbɝ. lɔɹd kaʊlɪn flɛd ðə taʊn fəɹ fɪɹ ə hɪz waɪfs spɪɹət.

"I find it difficult to lie, Lord Perrin," Seonid said dryly when he expressed doubt, but her tone quickly became as serious as her face, and her eyes were so intent that they alone began to make Perrin feel uneasy. "The dead are walking in So Habor. Lord Cowlin fled the town for fear of his wife's spirit.

ɪt simz ðəɹ wɑz daʊɾ əz tə haʊ ʃi daɪd. hɑɹdli ə mæn əɹ wʊmən ɪn ðə taʊn əz nɑt sin sʌmwʌn dɛd, ən ə ɡʊd mɛni hæv sin mɔɹ ðən wʌn.

It seems there was doubt as to how she died. Hardly a man or woman in the town has not seen someone dead, and a good many have seen more than one.

səm seɪ pipəl əv daɪd fɹəm ðə tʌtʃ ə sʌmwʌn dɛd. aɪ kænɑt vɛɹəfaɪ ðæt, bʌt pipəl əv daɪɾ ə fɹaɪt, ən ʌðɝz kəz ʌv ɪt. noʊ wʌn ɡoʊz aʊɾ ət naɪɾ ɪn soʊ hæbɝ, əɹ wɔks ɪndə ə ɹum ʌnənaʊnst. pipəl stʃɹaɪk aʊɾ ət ʃædoʊz ən sɝpɹaɪzəz wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ɪz tə hænd, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪv faʊn ə hʌzbənd, waɪf əɹ neɪbɝ dɛɾ ət ðɛɹ fit. ðɪs ɪz nɑt hɪstɛɹiə əɹ ə teɪl tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðə laɪk, bʌɾ ɪts ɹil. jə mʌs liv wʌn ʌv əs hɪɹ tə də wʌt wi kæn." pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. hi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə luz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪf i wɑz tə fɹi feɪl. mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹnən bɪɡæn tə wip ivən bɪfɔɹ i sɛd, "soʊ hæbɝ wɪl əv tə feɪs ɪts dɛɾ əloʊn." bʌt fɪɹ ə ðə dɛɾ oʊnli ɪkspleɪn soʊ mʌtʃ. meɪbi pipəl wɝ tu fɹaɪɾənd tə θɪŋk ʌv wɑʃɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðət fɪɹ wəd teɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ðət weɪ. ðeɪ dʒʌs dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ ɛnimɔɹ. ən wivəlz θɹaɪvɪŋ ɪn wɪntɝ, ɪn fɹizɪŋ koʊld? ðəɹ wɑz wɝs ɹɔŋ ɪn soʊ hæbɝ ðən spɪɹəts wɔkɪŋ, ən ɛvɹi ɪnstɪŋk toʊld ɪm tə liv əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn, wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk. hi pjʊɹli wɪʃt ðəɾ i kʊd.

Some say people have died from the touch of someone dead. I cannot verify that, but people have died of fright, and others because of it. No one goes out at night in So Habor, or walks into a room unannounced. People strike out at shadows and surprises with whatever is to hand, and sometimes they have found a husband, wife or neighbor dead at their feet. This is not hysteria or a tale to frighten children, Lord Perrin. I have never heard of the like, but it is real. You must leave one of us here to do what we can." Perrin shook his head slowly. He could not afford to lose an Aes Sedai if he was to free Faile. Mistress Arnon began to weep even before he said, "So Habor will have to face its dead alone." But fear of the dead only explained so much. Maybe people were too frightened to think of washing, but it seemed unlikely that fear would take everyone that way. They just did not seem to care anymore. And weevils thriving in winter, in freezing cold? There was worse wrong in So Habor than spirits walking, and every instinct told him to leave at a dead run, without looking back. He purely wished that he could.

tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən

CHAPTER 27

wʌt mʌs bi dʌn ðə wɪnoʊɪŋ tʊk pleɪs ɑn ðə snoʊi istɝn ɹɪvɝbæŋk, wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə kʌt ðə ʃɑɹp nɔɹθ wɪnd. mɛn ən wɪmən fɹəm ðə taʊn hɔl sæks əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒəz ɪn fɔɹ-hɔɹs wæɡənz ən wʌn-hɔɹs kɑɹts ivən bæɹoʊz pʊʃt baɪ hænd. nɔɹməli baɪɝz bɹɔt ðɛɹ oʊn wæɡənz tə ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz, əɹ ət wɝs ðə ɡɹeɪn ən dʒɹaɪd binz oʊnli hæd tə bi kæɹiɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðə wɔɹf, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə sɛndɪŋ ɪz kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz ɪndə soʊ hæbɝ. əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

What Must Be Done The winnowing took place on the snowy eastern riverbank, where there was nothing to cut the sharp north wind. Men and women from the town hauled sacks across the bridges in four-horse wagons and one-horse carts even barrows pushed by hand. Normally buyers brought their own wagons to the warehouses, or at worst the grain and dried beans only had to be carried as far as the wharf, but Perrin had no intention of sending his cart drivers into So Habor. Or anyone else, for that matter.

wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɹɔŋ ɪn ðət taʊn maɪt bi kætʃɪŋ. ɛniweɪ, ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz wɝ ənizi ɪnʌf əz ɪt wɑz, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə dɝɾi taʊnzfoʊk, pipəl u nɛvɝ spoʊk, bʌt læf nɝvəsli wən ðeɪ æksədɛntəli mɛt sʌmwʌnz aɪ. ðə ɡɹaɪmi-feɪs mɝtʃəns oʊvɝsiɪŋ ðə wɝk wɝ noʊ bɛɾɝ. ɪn ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz' neɪɾɪv kɛɹhin, mɝtʃəns wɝ klin, ɹɪspɛktəbəl pipəl, ət list aʊtwɝdli, hu vɛɹi sɛldəm twɪtʃt dʒʌs kəz sʌmwʌn muvd ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðɛɹ vɪʒən. bɪtwin mɝtʃəns wɪð ə tɛndənsi tə pɪɹ səspɪʃəsli əɾ ɛniwʌn ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ, ən taʊnzfoʊk u dʒɹæɡd ðɛɹ fit ɹɛkɹɔsɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒəz, klɪɹli ɹɪlʌktən tə ɡoʊ bæk ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ oʊn wɔlz, ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz wɝ ɹaɪɾ ɑn ɛdʒ. ðeɪ ɡæðɝɾ ɪn lɪɾəl klʌstɝz, peɪl, dɑɹk-klæd mɛn ən wɪmən, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hɪls ə ðɛɹ bɛl naɪvz ən piɹɪŋ ət ðə kɔlɝ loʊkəlz əz ɪf ət mɝɾɝəs mædmən.

Whatever was wrong in that town might be catching. Anyway, the drivers were uneasy enough as it was, frowning at the dirty townsfolk, people who never spoke, but laughed nervously when they accidentally met someone's eye. The grimy-faced merchants overseeing the work were no better. In the drivers' native Cairhien, merchants were clean, respectable people, at least outwardly, who very seldom twitched just because someone moved at the corner of their vision. Between merchants with a tendency to peer suspiciously at anyone they did not know, and townsfolk who dragged their feet recrossing the bridges, clearly reluctant to go back inside their own walls, the cart drivers were right on edge. They gathered in little clusters, pale, dark-clad men and women, gripping the hilts of their belt knives and peering at the caller locals as if at murderous madmen.

pɛɹɪn ɹoʊɾ əbaʊt sloʊli, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɪnoʊɪŋ, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə ɹoʊ ʌv kɑɹts ðət stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp ðə ɹaɪz ən aʊɾ ə saɪt weɪɾɪŋ tə bi loʊɾəd, əɹ ðə taʊnz wæɡənz ən kɑɹts ən bæɹoʊz ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒəz. hi meɪd ʃʊɹ i wɑz ɪn pleɪn vju. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ʌnkənsɝnd ʃəd sɛɾəl ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz nɝvz, jɛɾ ɪt sim tə. ɪnʌf ðət noʊ wʌn stɑɹɾəd ɹʌnɪŋ, ət list, ðoʊ ðeɪ kəntɪnjud tə lʊk əskæns ət ðə pipəl ə soʊ hæbɝ. ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns, tu, ən dʒʌst əz wɛl. lɛt ðə noʊʃən ðət səm ə ðoʊz foʊk maɪt nɑt bi əlaɪv ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə kɛɹhinɪnz hɛdz, ən hæf wəd wɪp ʌp ðɛɹ kɑɹt hɔɹsəz tə fli ðən ən ðɛɹ. moʊst ə ðə ɹɛs maɪt nɑt weɪt mʌtʃ pæs dɑɹk. ðət sɔɹɾ ə teɪl kəd twɪst ɛniwʌnz hɛd, kʌm naɪt. ðə wɑn sʌn, nɪɹli hɪɾən baɪ ɡɹeɪ oʊvɝkæst, stɪl sæt lɛs ðən hæfweɪ tə ɪts nundeɪ pik, jɛɾ ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə bi ðəɹ θɹu ðə naɪt. meɪbi mɔɹ ðən wʌn. hɪz dʒɔ nɑɾɪd wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə nɑt ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɪz tiθ, ən ivən nil bɪɡæn tə əvɔɪɾ ɪz skaʊlz. hi dɪd nɑt snæp əɾ ɛniwʌn. hi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə.

Perrin rode about slowly, watching the winnowing, examining the row of carts that stretched up the rise and out of sight waiting to be loaded, or the town's wagons and carts and barrows rolling across the bridges. He made sure he was in plain view. He was not sure why the sight of him pretending to be unconcerned should settle anyone else's nerves, yet it seemed to. Enough that no one started running, at least, though they continued to look askance at the people of So Habor. They kept their distance, too, and just as well. Let the notion that some of those folk might not be alive get into the Cairhienin's heads, and half would whip up their cart horses to flee then and there. Most of the rest might not wait much past dark. That sort of tale could twist anyone's head, come night. The wan sun, nearly hidden by gray overcast, still sat less than halfway to its noonday peak, yet increasingly it was obvious they would have to be there through the night. Maybe more than one. His jaw knotted with the effort of not grinding his teeth, and even Neald began to avoid his scowls. He did not snap at anyone. He just wanted to.

ɪt wɑz ən ɑɹdʒuəs pɹɑsɛs, ðə wɪnoʊɪŋ. ɛvɹi læst sæk hæd tə bi oʊpən ən ɛmptiɾ ɑntu lɑɹdʒ flæt wɪkɝ bæskəts, itʃ ʌv wɪtʃ tʊk tu pipəl tə tɔs ðə ɡɹeɪn əɹ binz. ðə koʊld wɪn kæɹiɾ əweɪ wivəlz ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə blæk flɛks, ən mɛn ən wɪmən wɪð woʊvən tu-hændəd fænz æɾəd tə ðə ɡʌsts. ə swɪf kɝən swɛpt əweɪ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət wɑz bloʊn ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt sun ðə snoʊ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk wɑz tʃɹæmpəld ʌndɝfʊɾ ən ðə ɡɹeɪ slʌʃ leɪɝd wɪð ɪnsɛks dɛɾ əɹ daɪɪŋ fɹəm ðə koʊld, ən ə lɪbɝəl koʊɾɪŋ ʌv oʊts ən bɑɹli spɛkəld wɪð ɹɛd binz. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə nu leɪɝ tə ɹipleɪs wʌt fit mæʃt ɪndə ðə snoʊ. wʌt wɑz lɛft ɑn ðə bæskəts sim klinɝ, ðoʊ, ɪf nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli klin wən ɪt wɑz pɔɹd bæk ɪndə ðə kɔɹs dʒut bæɡz, wɪtʃ hæd bɪn tɝn ɪnsaɪɾ aʊɾ ən biɾən fɪɹsli wɪð stɪks baɪ tʃɪlʒɹən tə ʃeɪk aʊt vɝmɪn. ðə ɹifɪl sæks wɛn ɪndə ðə kɛɹhinɪnz kɑɹts əz sun əz ðə tɑps wɝ taɪd, bʌt ðə paɪlz ʌv ɛmpti bæɡz ɡɹu əɾ ə pɹədɪdʒəs ɹeɪt.

It was an arduous process, the winnowing. Every last sack had to be opened and emptied onto large flat wicker baskets, each of which took two people to toss the grain or beans. The cold wind carried away weevils in a shower of black flecks, and men and women with woven two-handed fans added to the gusts. A swift current swept away everything that was blown into the river, but soon the snow on the riverbank was trampled underfoot and the gray slush layered with insects dead or dying from the cold, and a liberal coating of oats and barley speckled with red beans. There was always a new layer to replace what feet mashed into the snow. What was left on the baskets seemed cleaner, though, if not entirely clean when it was poured back into the coarse jute bags, which had been turned inside out and beaten fiercely with sticks by children to shake out vermin. The refilled sacks went into the Cairhienin's carts as soon as the tops were tied, but the piles of empty bags grew at a prodigious rate.

hi wɑz linɪŋ ɑn ðə pɑməl ə steɪɝz sæɾəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kælkjəleɪt wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz teɪkɪŋ tu hoʊl kɑɹt loʊdz fɹəm ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz tə fɪl wʌn ə hɪz kɑɹts wɪð ɡɹeɪn, wən bɹəleɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ waɪt mɛɹ ʌp bɪsaɪd hɪm, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ skɑɹlət kloʊk kloʊs əɡɛns ðə wɪnd wɪð wʌn ɹɛd-ɡlʌv hænd. ənʊɹə ɹeɪn ɪn ə fju peɪsɪz əweɪ, hɝ eɪdʒləs feɪs smuð ən ənɹiɾəbəl. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɪɹd tə bi ɡɪvɪŋ əm pɹaɪvəsi, jɛt ʃi wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ əbʌv wɪspɝz ivən wɪθaʊɾ ɛni tʃɹɪks ə ðə paʊɝ. smuð feɪs əɹ noʊ, hɝ bik ʌv ə noʊz ɡeɪv əɹ ə pɹɛɾətɔɹi lʊk tədeɪ. hɝ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz sim səm stʃɹeɪnʒ iɡəlz loʊɝd kɹɛst.

He was leaning on the pommel of Stayer's saddle, trying to calculate whether it was taking two whole cart loads from the warehouses to fill one of his carts with grain, when Berelain brought her white mare up beside him, holding her scarlet cloak close against the wind with one red-gloved hand. Annoura reined in a few paces away, her ageless face smooth and unreadable. The Aes Sedai appeared to be giving them privacy, yet she was close enough to hear anything above whispers even without any tricks of the Power. Smooth face or no, her beak of a nose gave her a predatory look today. Her beaded braids seemed some strange eagle's lowered crest.

"ju kænɑt seɪv ɛvɹiwʌn," bɹəleɪn sɛd kɑmli. əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɪŋk ə ðə taʊn, hɝ sɛnt wɑz ʃɑɹp wɪð ɝdʒənsi, ən ɹeɪzɝədʒd wɪð æŋɡɝ. "səmtaɪmz, jə mʌs tʃuz. soʊ hæbɝ ɪz lɔɹd kaʊlɪnz duɾi. hi hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə əbændən ɪz pipəl." nɑɾ æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪm, ðɛn.

"You cannot save everyone," Berelain said calmly. Away from the stink of the town, her scent was sharp with urgency, and razoredged with anger. "Sometimes, you must choose. So Habor is Lord Cowlin's duty. He had no right to abandon his people." Not angry with him, then.

pɛɹɪn fɹaʊnd. dɪd ʃi θɪŋk i fɛlt ɡɪlti? bælənst əɡɛns feɪlz laɪf, ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ə soʊ hæbɝ kəd nɑt bʌdʒ ðə skeɪlz ə hɛɹ. bʌɾ i tɝn ɪz beɪ soʊ hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹeɪ taʊn wɔlz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, nɑt ðə hɑloʊ-aɪd tʃɪlʒɹən paɪlɪŋ ʌp ɛmpti sæks. ə mæn dɪd wʌɾ i kʊd. wʌɾ i hæd tə. "dʌz ənʊɹə hæv ən əpɪnjən ɑn wʌts hæpənɪŋ hɪɹ?" hi ɡɹaʊld. kwaɪətli, bʌt sʌmhaʊ hi hæd noʊ daʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hɝd. "aɪv lɪɾəl aɪdiə wʌɾ ənʊɹə θɪŋks," bɹəleɪn ɹɪplaɪd, meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt tə loʊɝ əɹ vɔɪs. ʃi nɑɾ oʊnli dɪd nɑt kɛɹ u oʊvɝhɝd, ʃi wɑntəd tə bi hɝd. "ʃi ɪz nɑɾ əz fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ əz ʃi wʌns wɑz. əz aɪ wʌns θɔt ʃi wɑz. ɪts ʌp tə hɝ tə mɛnd wʌt ʃiz tɔɹn." wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi tɝn ən ɹoʊɾ əweɪ.

Perrin frowned. Did she think he felt guilty? Balanced against Faile's life, the troubles of So Habor could not budge the scales a hair. But he turned his bay so he was looking at the gray town walls across the river, not the hollow-eyed children piling up empty sacks. A man did what he could. What he had to. "Does Annoura have an opinion on what's happening here?" he growled. Quietly, but somehow he had no doubt the Aes Sedai heard. "I've little idea what Annoura thinks," Berelain replied, making no effort to lower her voice. She not only did not care who overheard, she wanted to be heard. "She is not as forthcoming as she once was. As I once thought she was. It is up to her to mend what she has torn." Without looking at the Aes Sedai, she turned and rode away.

ənʊɹə ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd, aɪz ənblɪŋkɪŋ ɑn pɛɹɪnz feɪs. "ju ɑɹ tɑvɝən, jɛs, bʌt jə ɑɹ stɪl oʊnli ə θɹɛɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, əz æm aɪ. ɪn ði ɛnd, ivən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪz dʒʌst ə θɹɛd tə bi woʊvən ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn. nɑɾ ivən ə tɑvɝən θɹɛd tʃuzəz haʊ ɪɾəl bi woʊvən."

Annoura remained behind, eyes unblinking on Perrin's face. "You are ta'veren, yes, but you are still only a thread in the Pattern, as am I. In the end, even the Dragon Reborn is just a thread to be woven into the Pattern. Not even a ta'veren thread chooses how it will be woven."

"ðoʊz θɹɛdz ɑɹ pipəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɛɹəli. "səmtaɪmz meɪbi pipəl doʊnt wɑnə bi woʊvən ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn wɪθaʊɾ ɛni seɪ."

"Those threads are people," Perrin said wearily. "Sometimes maybe people don't want to be woven into the Pattern without any say."

"æn jə θɪŋk ðɪs meɪks ə dɪfɝəns?" nɑt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ən ænsɝ, ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz ən hild əɹ faɪn-æŋkəl bɹaʊn mɛɹ æftɝ bɹəleɪn ɪn ə ɡæləp ðət fæn əɹ kloʊk bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"And you think this makes a difference?" Not waiting on an answer, she lifted her reins and heeled her fine-ankled brown mare after Berelain in a gallop that fanned her cloak behind her.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɑntəd wɝdz wɪð pɛɹɪn. "noʊ," hi toʊl siɑnɪd fɝmli æftɝ lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ, pæɾɪŋ steɪɝz nɛk. ɪt wɑz ðə ɹaɪɾɝ wɑntəd suðɪŋ, ðoʊ. hi wɑntəd tə bi əweɪ fɹəm soʊ hæbɝ. "aɪ sɛd noʊ, ən aɪ min noʊ." ʃi sæɾ əɹ sæɾəl stɪfli, ə peɪl lɪɾəl wʊmən kɑɹvd ʌv aɪs.

She was not the only Aes Sedai who wanted words with Perrin. "No," he told Seonid firmly after listening to her, patting Stayer's neck. It was the rider wanted soothing, though. He wanted to be away from So Habor. "I said no, and I mean no." She sat her saddle stiffly, a pale little woman carved of ice.

ɪksɛp ðəɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ dɑɹk koʊlz bɝnɪŋ, ən ʃi ɹikt ʌv əfɹʌntɪd fjʊɹi bɛɹli ɪn tʃɛk. siɑnɪd wɑz maɪld əz mɪlk-wɔɾɝ wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ ə waɪz wʌn. bɪhaɪn hɝ, ælhæɹəz dɑɹk feɪs wɑz ə stoʊn, ɡɹeɪ stʃɹikɪŋ ɪz kɝli blæk hɛɹ laɪk fɹɔst. wɪntɝz feɪs wɑz ɹɛɾ əbʌv ɪz kɝl mʌstæʃɪz. ðeɪ hæd tə æksɛpt wʌt pæs bɪtwin ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪz wʌnz, bʌt pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt. . . . ðə wɪnd wɪp ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝ kloʊks əbaʊt, livɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz fɹi fəɹ sɔɹdz ɪf nid bi.

Except that her eyes were dark coals burning, and she reeked of affronted fury barely in check. Seonid was mild as milk-water with the Wise Ones, but he was not a Wise One. Behind her, Alharra's dark face was a stone, gray streaking his curly black hair like frost. Wynter's face was red above his curled mustaches. They had to accept what passed between their Aes Sedai and the Wise Ones, but Perrin was not. . . . The wind whipped their Warder cloaks about, leaving their hands free for swords if need be.

ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, ðə kloʊks ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ən bɹaʊn, blu ən waɪt. ɪt wɑz iziɝ ɑn ðə stʌmək ðən siɪŋ əm meɪk pɑɹts ʌv ə mæn dɪsəpɪɹ. səm iziɝ.

Rippling in the wind, the cloaks shifted in shades of gray and brown, blue and white. It was easier on the stomach than seeing them make parts of a man disappear. Some easier.

"ɪf aɪ hæv tə, əl sɛn ɛdʒɹə tə bɹɪŋ jə bæk," hi wɔɹnd. hɝ feɪs steɪd koʊld, hɝ aɪz hɑt, jɛɾ ə kwɪvɝ ɹæn θɹu hɝ, sweɪɪŋ ðə smɔl waɪt dʒɛm hæŋɪŋ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd. nɑt fɹəm fɪɹ ʌv wʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz wəd də tə hɝ ɪf ʃi hæd tə bi bɹɔt bæk, dʒʌs fɹəm ðə seɪm əfɛns ət pɛɹɪn ðət meɪɾ əɹ sɛn ə hʊk θɔɹn. hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ əkʌstəm tə əfɛndɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑɾ ə hæbəɾ ə waɪz mæn ɡɑɾ ɪntu, bʌt ðəɹ sim noʊ weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt.

"If I have to, I'll send Edarra to bring you back," he warned. Her face stayed cold, her eyes hot, yet a quiver ran through her, swaying the small white gem hanging on her forehead. Not from fear of what the Wise Ones would do to her if she had to be brought back, just from the same offense at Perrin that made her scent a hooked thorn. He was growing accustomed to offending Aes Sedai. Not a habit a wise man got into, but there seemed no way out of it.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ju?" hi æsk mɑsʊɝi. "du jə wɑnə steɪ ɪn soʊ hæbɝ əz wɛl?" ðə slɪm wʊmən wɑz noʊn fəɹ spikɪŋ stʃɹeɪt tə ðə pɔɪnt, dɝɛkt əz ə ɡɹin fəɹ ɔl ʃi wɑz bɹaʊn, bʌt ʃi sɛd kɑmli, "wʊd jə nɑt sɛn ɛdʒɹə æftɝ mi, tu? ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni weɪz tə sɝv, ən wi kænɑɾ ɔlweɪz pɪk ðə weɪz wi wəd wɪʃ." wɪtʃ, kʌm tə θɪŋk, maɪt bi tə ðə pɔɪnt, ɪn ə weɪ. hi stɪl hæd noʊ aɪdiə waɪ ʃi vɪzəɾəd mæsimə ɪn sikɹət. dɪd ʃi səspɛk ðəɾ i nu? mɑsʊɝiz feɪs wɑz ə blæn mæsk. kɝklɪn wɔɹ ə bɔɹɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən, naʊ ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə soʊ hæbɝ. hi mænədʒ tə sim slʌmpt waɪl sɪɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ɪɹɛkt, wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝi ɪn ðə wɝld əɹ ə θɔɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ə mæn u bɪliv ðəɾ ə kɝklɪn wəd ɹɪtɝn ðə nɛks deɪ tə baɪ ə sɛkən pɪɡ ɪn ə poʊk.

"What about you?" he asked Masuri. "Do you want to stay in So Habor as well?" The slim woman was known for speaking straight to the point, direct as a Green for all she was Brown, but she said calmly, "Would you not send Edarra after me, too? There are many ways to serve, and we cannot always pick the ways we would wish." Which, come to think, might be to the point, in a way. He still had no idea why she visited Masema in secret. Did she suspect that he knew? Masuri's face was a bland mask. Kirklin wore a bored expression, now they were out of So Habor. He managed to seem slumped while sitting his horse erect, without a worry in the world or a thought in his head. A man who believed that of Kirklin would return the next day to buy a second pig in a poke.

ðə taʊnzfoʊk wɝk məkænɪkli əz ðə sʌn ɹoʊz haɪɝ, laɪk pipəl u wɑntəd tə luz ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ðə tæsk ət hæn ən fɪɹd ðə ɹɪtɝn ə mɛmɹiz wən ðeɪ stɑpt. pɛɹɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd soʊ hæbɝ wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪm fænsɪfəl. stɪl, hi θɔɾ i wɑz ɹaɪt.

The townsfolk worked mechanically as the sun rose higher, like people who wanted to lose themselves in the task at hand and feared the return of memories when they stopped. Perrin decided So Habor was making him fanciful. Still, he thought he was right.

ði ɛɹ bɪɑn ðə wɔlz stɪl lʊk tu dɪm, əz ðoʊ ə ʃeɪɾɪŋ klaʊd hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə taʊn.

The air beyond the walls still looked too dim, as though a shading cloud hung over the town.

ət nun, ðə kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz klɪɹd pætʃəz ə snoʊ ɑn ðə sloʊp ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ tə meɪk smɔl faɪɝz ən bɹu wik ti wɪð livz bɹuɪŋ ðɛɹ θɝd pɑt, əɹ meɪbi fɔɹθ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ti tə bi hæɾ ɪn ðə taʊn. səm ə ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz lʊkt ət ðə bɹɪdʒəz əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ tə ɛntɝ soʊ hæbɝ ən si wʌt ðeɪ kəd faɪn tə it. ə ɡlæns ət ðə dɝt-keɪk pipəl wɝkɪŋ ðə wɪnoʊɪŋ bæskəts sɛn əm bæk tə dɪɡ aʊt ðɛɹ smɔl bæɡz ʌv oʊtmil ən ɡɹaʊn eɪkɔɹn. ət lis ðeɪ nu ðət mɪks wɑz klin. ə fju aɪd ðə sæks ɔlɹɛɾi loʊɾəd ɑn ðə kɑɹts, bʌt ðə binz niɾəd tə bi soʊkt ən ðə ɡɹeɪn ɹʌn θɹu ðə lɑɹdʒ hænʒɹnɪlz ðət hæd bɪn lɛf bæk ɪn ðə kæmp, ən ðət wɑz æftɝ ðə kʊks pɪkt aʊɾ əz mɛni mɔɹ wivəlz əz ðeɪ θɔt mɛn kəd nɑt stʌmək iɾɪŋ. pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ æpətaɪt, nɑt fəɹ ðə klinəs bɹɛd, bʌɾ i wɑz dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wʌt pæs fəɹ ti fɹəm ə bæɾɝd tɪn kʌp wən lɑɾən faʊn hɪm.

At noon, the cart drivers cleared patches of snow on the slope rising from the river to make small fires and brew weak tea with leaves brewing their third pot, or maybe fourth. There had been no tea to be had in the town. Some of the drivers looked at the bridges as if thinking to enter So Habor and see what they could find to eat. A glance at the dirt-caked people working the winnowing baskets sent them back to dig out their small bags of oatmeal and ground acorn. At least they knew that mix was clean. A few eyed the sacks already loaded on the carts, but the beans needed to be soaked and the grain run through the large handrnills that had been left back in the camp, and that was after the cooks picked out as many more weevils as they thought men could not stomach eating. Perrin had no appetite, not for the cleanest bread, but he was drinking what passed for tea from a battered tin cup when Latian found him.

ðə kɛɹhinɪn dɪd nɑɾ æktʃəli  kʌm tə hɪm. ɪnstɛd, ðə ʃɔɹt mæn ɪn ðə stʃɹaɪp dɑɹk koʊt ɹoʊd sloʊli pæs ðə smɔl faɪɝ wɛɹ pɛɹɪn wɑz stændɪŋ, ðən ɹeɪn ɪn wɪð ə fɹaʊn ə lɪɾəl ʌpsloʊp. dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, lɑɾən lɪftəɾ ɪz ɡɛldɪŋz nɪɹ fɔɹhuf ən fɹaʊn əɾ ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs, hi dɪd lʊk ʌp twaɪs tə si wɛðɝ pɛɹɪn wɑz kʌmɪŋ.

The Cairhienin did not actually come to him. Instead, the short man in the striped dark coat rode slowly past the small fire where Perrin was standing, then reined in with a frown a little upslope. Dismounting, Latian lifted his gelding's near forehoof and frowned at it. Of course, he did look up twice to see whether Perrin was coming.

wɪð ə saɪ, pɛɹɪn ɹɪtɝn ðə dɛntɪd kʌp tə ðə blɑki lɪɾəl wʊmən i hæd bɑɹoʊɾ ɪt fɹʌm, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝ u spɹɛɾ əɹ dɑɹk skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi. ən ɡɹɪn ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ət lɑɾən.

With a sigh, Perrin returned the dented cup to the blocky little woman he had borrowed it from, a graying cart driver who spread her dark skirts in a curtsy. And grinned and shook her head at Latian.

laɪkli, ʃi kəd snik tɛn taɪmz əz wɛl əz ðə fɛloʊ. nild, skwɑɾɪŋ baɪ ðə faɪɝ wɪð ɪz hænz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ənʌðɝ tɪn kʌp, læft aʊt laʊd soʊ hɑɹɾ i hæd tə waɪp ə tiɹ fɹəm ɪz aɪ. meɪbi hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ kɹeɪzi. laɪt, bʌt ðɪs pleɪs ɡeɪv ə mæn tʃɪɹfəl θɔts.

Likely, she could sneak ten times as well as the fellow. Neald, squatting by the fire with his hands wrapped around another tin cup, laughed out loud so hard he had to wipe a tear from his eye. Maybe he was beginning to go crazy. Light, but this place gave a man cheerful thoughts.

lɑɾən stʃɹeɪɾənd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk pɛɹɪn ə lɛɡ ən seɪ, "aɪ si ju, maɪ lɔɹd," ðən dʌk bæk daʊn tə snætʃ ʌp ðə fɔɹɛlɪɡ əɡɛn laɪk ə ful. jə dɪd nɑt ɡɹæb əɾ ə hɔɹsəz lɛɡz ðət weɪ ənlɛs jə wɑntəd kɪkɪŋ. bʌt ðɛn, pɛɹɪn ɪkspɛktəd nʌθɪŋ bʌt fulɪʃnəs, ɹɪli. fɝs ðəɹ wɑz lɑɾənz pleɪɪŋ ət biɪŋ il, wɪð ɪz ʃoʊldɝ-lɔŋ hɛɹ taɪɾ ɔf ɪn ə teɪl ət ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk ɪn wik ɪməteɪʃən ə haʊ il kʌt ðɛɹz, ən naʊ ðə mæn wɑz pleɪɪŋ ət biɪŋ ə spaɪ. pɛɹɪn ɹɛstəɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə ɡɛldɪŋz nɛk tə suð ði ænəməl æftɝ ɔl ðət snætʃɪŋ ən pʊɾ ən ɪntʃɹəstəd lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs əz i pɪɹɾ əɾ ə huf ðət hæɾ æbsəlutli nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð ɪt. ɪksɛp fəɹ ə nɪk ɪn ðə ʃu wɛɹ ði aɪɝn maɪt bɹeɪk ɪn ə fju deɪz ɪf ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹipleɪst. hɪz hænz ɪtʃt fəɹ fɛɹiɝz tulz. ɪt sim jɪɹz sɪns i hæd tʃeɪnʒd ə hɔɹsəz ʃuz, əɹ wɝkt ə fɔɹdʒ.

Latian straightened long enough to make Perrin a leg and say, "I see you, my Lord," then ducked back down to snatch up the foreleg again like a fool. You did not grab at a horse's legs that way unless you wanted kicking. But then, Perrin expected nothing but foolishness, really. First there was Latian's playing at being Aiel, with his shoulder-long hair tied off in a tail at the nape of his neck in weak imitation of how Aiel cut theirs, and now the man was playing at being a spy. Perrin rested a hand on the gelding's neck to soothe the animal after all that snatching and put an interested look on his face as he peered at a hoof that had absolutely nothing wrong with it. Except for a nick in the shoe where the iron might break in a few days if it was not replaced. His hands itched for farrier's tools. It seemed years since he had changed a horse's shoes, or worked a forge.

"mæstɝ beɪlwɝ sɛnz wɝd, maɪ lɔɹd," lɑɾən sɛd sɔfli, hɛd daʊn. "hɪz fɹɛn ɪz tʃɹævlɪŋ tə sɛl ɪz wɛɹz, bʌɾ ɪz ɪkspɛktəd bæk təmɑɹoʊ əɹ ðə nɛks deɪ. hi sɛd tə æsk wɛðɝ ɪɾəl bi ɔl ɹaɪɾ ɪf wi kætʃ ʌp tə jə ðɛn." piɹɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz bɛli ət ðə wɪnoʊɝz daʊn baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ, hi æɾəd, "ðoʊ ɪt hɑɹdli lʊks əz ɪf jəl bi əweɪ bɪfɔɹ." pɛɹɪn skaʊl daʊn ət ðə wɪnoʊɪŋ. hi skaʊld ət ðə laɪn ə kɑɹts weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝn tə bi loʊɾəd, ət ðə hæf dʌzən əɹ soʊ ðəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd ðɛɹ kænvəs kʌvɝz læʃt daʊn. wʌn ə ðoʊz hɛl ðə fɝst ə ðə lɛðɝ fəɹ pætʃɪŋ buts ən kændəlz ən sʌtʃ. noʊ ɔɪl, ðoʊ. ðə læmp ɔɪl ɪn soʊ hæbɝ smɛld əz ɹænsɪɾ əz ðə kʊkɪŋ ɔɪl. wʌɾ ɪf ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz bɹɔt wɝɾ ə feɪl? ən æktʃəwəl saɪɾɪŋ, pɝhæps? hi wəd ɡɪv ɛniθɪŋ tə tɔk tə sʌmwʌn u hæd sin hɝ, kəd tɛl ɪm ʃi wɑz ənhɑɹmd. wʌɾ ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɪɡæn tə muv sʌɾənli? "tɛl beɪlwɝ nɑt tə weɪt tu lɔŋ," hi ɡɹaʊld.

"Master Balwer sends word, my Lord," Latian said softly, head down. "His friend is traveling to sell his wares, but is expected back tomorrow or the next day. He said to ask whether it will be all right if we catch up to you then." Peering under the horse's belly at the winnowers down by the river, he added, "Though it hardly looks as if you will be away before." Perrin scowled down at the winnowing. He scowled at the line of carts waiting their turn to be loaded, at the half dozen or so that already had their canvas covers lashed down. One of those held the first of the leather for patching boots and candles and such. No oil, though. The lamp oil in So Habor smelled as rancid as the cooking oil. What if Gaul and the Maidens brought word of Faile? An actual sighting, perhaps? He would give anything to talk to someone who had seen her, could tell him she was unharmed. What if the Shaido began to move suddenly? "Tell Balwer not to wait too long," he growled.

"æz fəɹ mi, əl bi əweɪ ɪnsaɪd ði aʊɝ."

"As for me, I'll be away inside the hour."

hi wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz ɪz wɝd. moʊst ə ðə kɑɹts ən dʒɹaɪvɝz hæd tə bi lɛf bɪhaɪn tə meɪk ðə wʌn-deɪ dʒɝni bæk tə kæmp ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn, ən kaɪɹən ən ɪz ɡɹin-hɛlməɾɪd soʊlʒɝz tə ɡɑɹd ðɛm, wɪð ɔɹɾɝz ðət noʊ wʌn wɑz tə kɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒəz. koʊld-aɪd, əpɪɹɪŋ kəmplitli ɹəkʌvɝd fɹəm ɪz bɹeɪkdaʊn, ðə ɡildænɪn əʃʊɹɾ ɪm ðəɾ i wɑz fɪɾ ən ɹɛɾi. vɛɹi laɪkli, ɔɹɾɝz əɹ nɑt, hi wəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ɪndə soʊ hæbɝ dʒʌs tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf i wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, siɑnɪd hæd tə bi faʊnd. ʃi wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli haɪɾɪŋ, jɛt ʃi hæd lɝn ə hɪz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, ænd, livɪŋ əɹ wɔɹɾɝz tə hoʊld əɹ hɔɹs kwaɪɾ oʊpənli, ʃi dɑdʒd əbaʊɾ ɑn fʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip kɑɹts bɪtwin hɝsɛlf ən hɪm. ðə peɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt haɪɾ əɹ sɛnt, ðoʊ, əɹ ɪf ʃi kʊd, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən i tʃɹækt əɹ daʊn kwɪkli, ən ɪndɪɡnənt wən i mɑɹtʃt əɹ tə hɝ hɔɹs əhɛɾ ə steɪɝ. ivən soʊ, hi wɑz wɛl ʌndɝ ði aʊɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm soʊ hæbɝ, wɪð ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɪŋ ə ɹɛɾ ɑɹmɝ ɝaʊn bɹəleɪn, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn sɝaʊndɪŋ ði eɪt loʊɾəd kɑɹts ðət tʃɹʌndəld əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn ðə θɹi ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ bænɝz, ən nild ɡɹɪnɪŋ fəɹ ɔl i wɑz wɝθ. nɑt tə mɛnʃən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃæɾ ʌp ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də ɪf ðə fɛloʊ ɹɪli wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. əz sun əz ðə ɹaɪz hɪd soʊ hæbɝ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, hi fɛl ðə lusənɪŋ ʌv ə nɑɾ i hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ðət lɛft oʊnli tɛn ʌðɝz, ən ə nɑɾ ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns twɪstɪŋ ɪz bɛli. bɹəleɪnz ɑbviəs sɪmpəθi kəd nɑt lusən ðoʊz.

He was as good as his word. Most of the carts and drivers had to be left behind to make the one-day journey back to camp on their own, and Kireyin and his green-helmeted soldiers to guard them, with orders that no one was to cross the bridges. Cold-eyed, appearing completely recovered from his breakdown, the Ghealdanin assured him that he was fit and ready. Very likely, orders or not, he would be going back into So Habor just to convince himself he was not afraid. Perrin did not waste time trying to talk him out of it. For one thing, Seonid had to be found. She was not precisely hiding, yet she had learned of his departure, and, leaving her Warders to hold her horse quite openly, she dodged about on foot trying to keep carts between herself and him. The pale Aes Sedai could not hide her scent, though, or if she could, she did not know it was necessary. She was surprised when he tracked her down quickly, and indignant when he marched her to her horse ahead of Stayer. Even so, he was well under the hour riding away from So Habor, with the Winged Guards making their ring of red armor around Berelain, the Two Rivers men surrounding the eight loaded carts that trundled along behind the three remaining banners, and Neald grinning for all he was worth.
