Not to mention trying to chat up the Aes Sedai. Perrin did not know what to do if the fellow really was going mad. As soon as the rise hid So Habor behind them, he felt the loosening of a knot he had not realized was riding between his shoulders. That left only ten others, and a knot of impatience twisting his belly. Berelain's obvious sympathy could not loosen those.

nilz ɡeɪtweɪ tʊk əm fɹəm ðə snoʊ-kʌvɝd fil tə ðə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɡɹaʊn əmɪd ðə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹiz, fɔɹ liɡz ɪn ə stɛp, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt weɪt fəɹ ðə hændfʊl ə kɑɹts tə kʌm θɹu. hi θɔɾ i hɝd bɹəleɪn meɪk ə vɛkst saʊnd wən i buɾɪd steɪɝ tə ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt, bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛns ə stɪlnəs wən i ɹoʊɾ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛnz tɛns ən hʌts. ðə sʌn stɪl hʌŋ nɑt tu fɑɹ ɔf oʊvɝhɛɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ noʊ kʊkpɑts ɑn ðə faɪɝz ən vɛɹi fju ʌv ðə mɛn ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə kæmpfaɪɝz, hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ kloʊks kloʊs ən piɹɪŋ ɪntɛnli ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. ə hændfʊl wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹʌf stulz ðət bæn kɹeɪ nu haʊ tə meɪk; ðə ɹɛst stʊɾ əɹ skwɑɾɪd. noʊ wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz lʊkt ʌp. sɝɾənli noʊ wʌn keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə teɪk ɪz hɔɹs. nɑt stɪlnəs, hi ɹilaɪzd. tɛnʃən.

Neald's gateway took them from the snow-covered field to the small clearing of the Traveling ground amid the towering trees, four leagues in a step, but Perrin did not wait for the handful of carts to come through. He thought he heard Berelain make a vexed sound when he booted Stayer to a quick trot, back toward the camp. Or maybe it was one of the Aes Sedai. Much more likely. There was a sense of stillness when he rode in among the Two Rivers men's tents and huts. The sun still hung not too far off overhead in the gray sky, but there were no cookpots on the fires and very few of the men gathered around the campfires, holding their cloaks close and peering intently into the flames. A handful were sitting on the rough stools that Ban Crawe knew how to make; the rest stood or squatted. No one so much as looked up. Certainly no one came running to take his horse. Not stillness, he realized. Tension.

ðə smɛl sʌmhaʊ maɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv ə baʊ dʒɹɔn tə ðə pɔɪn ə bɹeɪkɪŋ. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ ðə kɹik.

The smell somehow minded him of a bow drawn to the point of breaking. He could almost hear the creak.

əz i dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp tɛnt, dænɪl əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə loʊ il tɛns, wɔkɪŋ fæst.

As he dismounted in front of the red-striped tent, Dannil appeared from the direction of the low Aiel tents, walking fast.

səlɪn ən ɛdʒɹə, wʌn ə ðə waɪz wʌnz, wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm, ən kipɪŋ ʌp izəli ðoʊ niðɝ əpɪɹd tə hɝi. səlɪnz feɪs wɑz ə sʌn-dɑɹk lɛðɝ mæsk. ɛdʒɹəz, bɛɹli ɹɪvil baɪ ðə dɑɹk ʃɔl ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd, wɑz ən ɪmədʒ ə kɑm. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ bʌlki skɝts, ʃi meɪɾ əz lɪɾəl saʊn əz ðə waɪt-hɛɹd meɪɾən, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə feɪn klɪŋk fɹəm əɹ ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi bɹeɪslɪts ən nɛkləsɪz. dænɪl wɑz tʃuɪŋ ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn θɪk mʌstæʃ, æbsənli pʊlɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən ɪntʃ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ɹʌf lɛðɝ skæbɝɾ ən ʃʌvɪŋ ɪt bæk hɑɹd. pʊl ən ʃʌv. hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ.

Sulin and Edarra, one of the Wise Ones, were following him, and keeping up easily though neither appeared to hurry. Sulin's face was a sun-dark leather mask. Edarra's, barely revealed by the dark shawl wrapped around her head, was an image of calm. Despite her bulky skirts, she made as little sound as the white-haired Maiden, not so much as a faint clink from her gold and ivory bracelets and necklaces. Dannil was chewing the edge of one thick mustache, absently pulling his sword an inch out of its rough leather scabbard and shoving it back hard. Pull and shove. He drew a deep breath before speaking.

"ðə meɪɾənz bɹɔɾ ɪn faɪv ʃeɪɾoʊ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ɑɹɡændə tʊk əm oʊvɝ tə ðə ɡildænɪn tɛns tə pʊɾ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən. mæsiməz wɪð ðɛm."

"The Maidens brought in five Shaido, Lord Perrin. Arganda took them over to the Ghealdanin tents to put them to the question. Masema's with them."

pɛɹɪn bɹʌʃt əsaɪd mæsiməz pɹɛzəns ɪnsaɪd ðə kæmp. "waɪ dɪd jə lɛɾ ɑɹɡændə teɪk ðɛm?" hi æskt ɛdʒɹə. dænɪl kəd nɑɾ əv stɑpt ɪt, bʌt ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ ə dɪfɹən pɹɑpəzɪʃən.

Perrin brushed aside Masema's presence inside the camp. "Why did you let Arganda take them?" he asked Edarra. Dannil could not have stopped it, but the Wise Ones were a different proposition.

ɛdʒɹə əpɪɹd nɑt mʌtʃ oʊldɝ ðən pɛɹɪn, jɛɾ əɹ kul blu aɪz sim tə hæv sin fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən i ɛvɝ wʊd. ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ɪn ə ɹæɾəl ə bɹeɪslɪts. ən wɪð ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɪmpeɪʃəns. "ivən ʃeɪɾoʊ noʊ haʊ tə ɛmbɹeɪs peɪn, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. ɪɾəl teɪk deɪz tə bɹɪŋ ɛni ʌv əm tə tɔk, ən ðəɹ sim noʊ ɹizən tə weɪt."

Edarra appeared not much older than Perrin, yet her cool blue eyes seemed to have seen far more than he ever would. She folded her arms beneath her breasts in a rattle of bracelets. And with a touch of impatience. "Even Shaido know how to embrace pain, Perrin Aybara. It will take days to bring any of them to talk, and there seemed no reason to wait."

ɪf ɛdʒɹəz aɪz wɝ kul, səlɪnz wɝ blu aɪs. "maɪ spɝsɪstɝz ən aɪ cʊɾə dʌn ɪt fæstɝ aʊɝsɛlvz, ə lɪɾəl, bʌt dænɪl luɪn sɛd jə wɑntəd noʊ bloʊz stʃɹʌk. dʒɝɑɹɾ ɑɹɡændə ɪz ən ɪmpeɪʃən mæn, ən i mɪstʃɹʌsts ʌs." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi wəɾ əv spæɾ ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑɾ il. "ju meɪ nɑt lɝn mʌtʃ, ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðeɪ ɑɹ stoʊn dɑɡz. ðəl jil sloʊli, ən əz lɪɾəl əz pɑsəbəl. ɪn ðɪs, ɪts ɔlweɪz nɛsəsɛɹi tə pʊt təɡɛðɝ ə lɪɾəl fɹəm wʌn wɪð ə lɪɾəl fɹəm ənʌðɝ tə meɪk ə pɪktʃɝ." ɛmbɹeɪs peɪn. ðəɹ hæd tə bi peɪn, wən jə pʊɾ ə mæn tə ðə kwɛstʃən. hi hæd nɑt lɛt ðət θɔt fɔɹm ɪn ɪz hɛd bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. bʌt tə ɡɛt feɪl bæk. . . .

If Edarra's eyes were cool, Sulin's were blue ice. "My spearsisters and I could have done it faster ourselves, a little, but Dannil Lewin said you wanted no blows struck. Gerard Arganda is an impatient man, and he mistrusts us." She sounded as though she would have spat if she were not Aiel. "You may not learn much, in any case. They are Stone Dogs. They will yield slowly, and as little as possible. In this, it is always necessary to put together a little from one with a little from another to make a picture." Embrace pain. There had to be pain, when you put a man to the question. He had not let that thought form in his head before this. But to get Faile back. . . .

"hæv sʌmbɑɾi ɹʌb steɪɝ daʊn," hi sɛd ɹʌfli, θɹʌstɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ət dænɪl.

"Have somebody rub Stayer down," he said roughly, thrusting the reins at Dannil.

ðə ɡildænɪn pɔɹʃən ə ðə kæmp kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə ɹud ʃɛltɝz ən hæfəzɝdli pleɪs tɛns ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn. hɪɹ, ðə pikt kænvəs tɛns stʊɾ ɪn pɹɪsaɪs ɹoʊz, moʊst wɪð ə stil-tɪp koʊn ə lænsɪz stændɪŋ ət ði ɛntʃɹi flæps ən sæɾəld hɔɹsəz tɛðɝɾ ət ðə saɪd, ɹɛɾi tə maʊnt. ðə flɪkɪŋ ə ðə hɔɹsəz' teɪlz ən ðə lɔŋ stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðə lænsɪz, lɪftɪŋ ɑn ə koʊl bɹiz, wɝ ði oʊnli dɪsɔɹɾɝd θɪŋz tə bi sin. ðə pæðz bɪtwin ðə tɛns wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm wɪdθ, ən ə stʃɹeɪt laɪn cʊɾə bɪn dʒɹɔn θɹu ðə ɹoʊz ə kʊkfaɪɝz.

The Ghealdanin portion of the camp could not have been more different from the rude shelters and haphazardly placed tents of the Two Rivers men. Here, the peaked canvas tents stood in precise rows, most with a steel-tipped cone of lances standing at the entry flaps and saddled horses tethered at the side, ready to mount. The flicking of the horses' tails and the long streamers on the lances, lifting on a cold breeze, were the only disordered things to be seen. The paths between the tents were all the same width, and a straight line could have been drawn through the rows of cookfires.

ivən ðə kɹisɪz ɪn ðə kænvəs, fɹəm wɛɹ ðə tɛns hæd bɪn foʊldəɾ əweɪ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə kɑɹts əntɪl ðə snoʊz keɪm, meɪd stʃɹeɪt laɪnz. ɔl ɔɹɾɝli ən nit.

Even the creases in the canvas, from where the tents had been folded away at the bottom of carts until the snows came, made straight lines. All orderly and neat.

ə smɛl ʌv oʊtmil pɔɹədʒ ən bɔɪld eɪkɔɹn hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən səm ɡɹin-koʊɾəd mɛn wɝ skɹeɪpɪŋ ðə læst ə ðə mɪddeɪ mil fɹəm ðɛɹ tɪn pleɪts wɪð ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi skaʊɝɪŋ aʊt ðə kʊkpɑts. nʌn ʃoʊɾ ɛni saɪn ə tɛnʃən. ðeɪ wɝ dʒʌst iɾɪŋ ən duɪŋ tʃɔɹz, wɪð əbaʊɾ ikwəl plɛʒɝ. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðət hæd tə bi dʌn.

A smell of oatmeal porridge and boiled acorn hung in the air, and some green-coated men were scraping the last of the midday meal from their tin plates with their fingers. Others were already scouring out the cookpots. None showed any sign of tension. They were just eating and doing chores, with about equal pleasure. It was something that had to be done.

ə lɑɹdʒ nɑɾ ə mɛn stʊd ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ə ɹɪŋ nɪɹ ðə ʃɑɹpən steɪks ðət mɑɹk ði aʊɾɝ ɛdʒ ə ðə kæmp. noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf wɔɹ ðə ɡɹin koʊts ən bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪts ʌv ɡildænɪn lænsɝz. səm ə ði ʌðɝz kæɹid lænsɪz əɹ hæd sɔɹdz bɛltəɾ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɹʌmpəl koʊts. ðoʊz ɹeɪnʒd fɹəm faɪn sɪlk əɹ ɡʊd wʊl tə ðə pɪkɪŋz ʌv ə ɹæɡbæɡ, bʌt nʌn kəd bi kɔl klin ɪksɛpt ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən tə soʊ hæbɝ. jə kəɾ ɔlweɪz tɛl mæsiməz mɛn, ivən fɹəm ðə bæk.

A large knot of men stood gathered in a ring near the sharpened stakes that marked the outer edge of the camp. No more than half wore the green coats and burnished breastplates of Ghealdanin lancers. Some of the others carried lances or had swords belted over their rumpled coats. Those ranged from fine silk or good wool to the pickings of a ragbag, but none could be called clean except in comparison to So Habor. You could always tell Masema's men, even from the back.

ənʌðɝ smɛl keɪm tə hɪm əz i əpɹoʊtʃt ðə sɝkəl ə mɛn. ðə smɛl ə mit ɹoʊstɪŋ. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə mʌfəl saʊn ðəɾ i tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə hɪɹ. wən i bɪɡæn pʊʃɪŋ ɪz weɪ θɹu, ðə soʊlʒɝz lʊkt ɝaʊn əɾ ɪm ən ɡeɪv weɪ ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. mæsiməz mɛn stɑɹɾəd bæk, mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt jɛloʊ aɪz ən ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. iðɝ weɪ, hi ɡeɪn pæsədʒ tə ðə fɹʌnt.

Another smell came to him as he approached the circle of men. The smell of meat roasting. And there was a muffled sound that he tried not to hear. When he began pushing his way through, the soldiers looked around at him and gave way grudgingly. Masema's men started back, muttering about yellow eyes and Shadowspawn. Either way, he gained passage to the front.

fɔɹ tɔl mɛn, ɹɛd-hɛɹɾ əɹ peɪl ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ-ænd-bɹaʊn keɪɾɪn'-sɔɹ, leɪ baʊnd wɪð ðɛɹ ɹɪsts læʃt tə ðɛɹ æŋkəlz ɪn ðə smɔl ə ðɛɹ bæks ən staʊt lɛŋθs ə bɹæntʃ taɪd bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ niz ən ɛlboʊz. ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ bæɾɝd ən bɹuzd, ən ðeɪ hæd wɑɾəd ɹæɡz taɪd bɪtwin ðɛɹ tiθ. ðə fɪfθ mæn wɑz neɪkəd, steɪkt aʊt bɪtwin fɔɹ staʊt pɛɡz dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən stʃɹɛtʃt soʊ taɪɾ ɪz sɪnuz stʊɾ aʊt. hi θɹæʃt əz mʌtʃ əz ɪz baɪndɪŋ əlaʊd, ðoʊ, ən haʊld ɪndə ðə ɹæɡz stʌfɪŋ ɪz maʊð, ə mʌfəl bɛloʊ ʌv æɡəni. hɑt koʊlz meɪɾ ə smɔl klʌstɝ ɑn ɪz bɛli, ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf ə feɪn smoʊk. ɪt wɑz ðə smɛl ə blɪstɝɪŋ flɛʃ ðət pɛɹɪnz noʊz hæd kɑt. ðə koʊlz klʌŋ tə ðə stʃɹɛtʃt mænz skɪn, ən ɛvɹi taɪm ɪz ɹaɪðɪŋ mænədʒ tə θɹoʊ wʌn ɔf, ə ɡɹɪnɪŋ fɛloʊ ɪn ə fɪlθi ɡɹin sɪlk koʊt, skwɑɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɪm, juzd ə pɛɹ ə tɑŋz tə ɹipleɪs ɪt wɪð ənʌðɝ fɹəm ə pɑtfəl mɛltɪŋ ə sɝkəl ə mʌɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. pɛɹɪn nu hɪm. hɪz neɪm wɑz hɑɹi, ən i laɪk tə kəlɛkt ɪɹz stʃɹʌŋ ɑn ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd. mɛnz ɪɹz, wɪmənz ɪɹz, tʃɪlʒɹənz ɪɹz; ɪt nɛvɝ maɪndəd tə hɑɹi. wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, pɛɹɪn stʃɹoʊd fɔɹwɝɾ ən kɪk ðə lɪɾəl paɪl ə koʊlz ɔf ðə baʊn mæn. səm ə ðɛm stʃɹʌk hɑɹi, hu dʒʌmp bæk wɪð ə stɑɹɾəld skwil ðət tɝn tə ə ʃɹik wən ɪz hæn keɪm daʊn ɪn ðə pɑt. hi tɑpəld oʊvɝ saɪdweɪz, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ɪz bɝn hæn ən ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn, ə wizəl ɪn ə hjumən skɪn. "ðə sævədʒ meɪks ə ʃæm, eɪbɑɹə," mæsimə sɛd. pɛɹɪn hæd nɑɾ ivən noʊɾəst ðə mæn stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, feɪs laɪk ə skaʊlɪŋ stoʊn bɪniθ ɪz ʃeɪv skælp. hɪz dɑɹk fivɝɾ aɪz hɛld ə mɛʒɝ ə kəntɛmpt. ðə sɛn ə mædnəs skɪɾɝd θɹu ðə stɪŋk ə bɝn flɛʃ. "aɪ noʊ ðɛm. ðeɪ pɹitɛn tə fil peɪn, bʌt ðeɪ də nɑt; nɑt ðə weɪ ʌðɝ mɛn du. jə mʌs bi wɪlɪŋ ən eɪbəl tə hɝɾ ə stoʊn tə meɪk wʌn ə ðɛm tɔk."

Four tall men, red-haired or pale in the gray-and-brown cadin'-sor, lay bound with their wrists lashed to their ankles in the small of their backs and stout lengths of branch tied behind their knees and elbows. Their faces were battered and bruised, and they had wadded rags tied between their teeth. The fifth man was naked, staked out between four stout pegs driven into the ground and stretched so tight his sinews stood out. He thrashed as much as his binding allowed, though, and howled into the rags stuffing his mouth, a muffled bellow of agony. Hot coals made a small cluster on his belly, giving off a faint smoke. It was the smell of blistering flesh that Perrin's nose had caught. The coals clung to the stretched man's skin, and every time his writhing managed to throw one off, a grinning fellow in a filthy green silk coat, squatting beside him, used a pair of tongs to replace it with another from a potful melting a circle of mud in the ground. Perrin knew him. His name was Hari, and he liked to collect ears strung on a leather cord. Men's ears, women's ears, children's ears; it never minded to Hari. Without thinking, Perrin strode forward and kicked the little pile of coals off the bound man. Some of them struck Hari, who jumped back with a startled squeal that turned to a shriek when his hand came down in the pot. He toppled over sideways, cradling his burned hand and glaring at Perrin, a weasel in a human skin. "The savage makes a sham, Aybara," Masema said. Perrin had not even noticed the man standing there, face like a scowling stone beneath his shaved scalp. His dark fevered eyes held a measure of contempt. The scent of madness skittered through the stink of burned flesh. "I know them. They pretend to feel pain, but they do not; not the way other men do. You must be willing and able to hurt a stone to make one of them talk."

ɑɹɡændə, ɹɪdʒəd bɪsaɪd mæsimə, wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz hænd ʃʊk. "pɝhæps jə ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə luz jəɹ waɪf, eɪbɑɹə," hi ɡɹeɪɾɪd, "bʌɾ əl nɑt luz maɪ kwin!" "ɪɾ əz tə bi dʌn," ɛɹæm sɛd, hæf pliɾɪŋ, hæf dɪmændɪŋ. hi wɑz ɑn mæsiməz ʌðɝ saɪd, klʌtʃɪŋ ði ɛdʒəz ə hɪz ɡɹin kloʊk əz ɪf tə kip ɪz hænz fɹəm ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. hɪz aɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɾ əz mæsiməz. "ju tɔt mi ðəɾ ə mæn dʌz wʌɾ i mʌst."

Arganda, rigid beside Masema, was gripping his sword hilt so hard that his hand shook. "Perhaps you are willing to lose your wife, Aybara," he grated, "but I will not lose my queen!" "It has to be done," Aram said, half pleading, half demanding. He was on Masema's other side, clutching the edges of his green cloak as if to keep his hands from the sword on his back. His eyes were almost as hot as Masema's. "You taught me that a man does what he must."

pɛɹɪn fɔɹst ɪz fɪsts tə ənnət. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn, fəɹ feɪl.

Perrin forced his fists to unknot. What had to be done, for Faile.

bɹəleɪn ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm pʊʃɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, bɹəleɪn ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ əɹ noʊz slaɪtli ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə mæn stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt bɪtwin ðə pɛɡz. ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə pis ʌv wʊd fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ɛdʒɹə ən səlɪn wɝ wɪð ðɛm, niðɝ mɔɹ əfɛktəd. səm ə ðə ɡildænɪn soʊlʒɝz fɹaʊn ət ðə tu il wɪmən ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɹɛθ. mæsiməz ɹʌmpəld, dɝɾi-feɪst mɛn ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ il ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əlaɪk, bʌt moʊst ɛdʒd əweɪ fɹəm ðə θɹi wɔɹɾɝz, ən ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt wɝ pʊld əweɪ baɪ ðɛɹ kəmpænjənz. səm fulz nu ðə lɪməts ə stupɪɾɪti. mæsimə ɡlɛɹɾ ət bɹəleɪn wɪð bɝnɪŋ aɪz bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə pɹitɛnd ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst. səm fulz nu noʊ lɪməts.

Berelain and the Aes Sedai came pushing through the crowd, Berelain wrinkling her nose slightly at the sight of the man stretched out between the pegs. The three Aes Sedai might have been looking at a piece of wood for all their expression. Edarra and Sulin were with them, neither more affected. Some of the Ghealdanin soldiers frowned at the two Aiel women and muttered under their breath. Masema's rumpled, dirty-faced men glared at Aiel and Aes Sedai alike, but most edged away from the three Warders, and those who did not were pulled away by their companions. Some fools knew the limits of stupidity. Masema glared at Berelain with burning eyes before deciding to pretend she did not exist. Some fools knew no limits.

bɛndɪŋ, pɛɹɪn əntaɪd ðə ɹæɡ ɝaʊn ðə pɛɡd mænz maʊθ ən tʌɡd ðə wɑd fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. hi dʒʌs mænədʒ tə snætʃ ɪz hæn bæk fɹəm ə snæp əz vɪʃəs əz ɛni steɪɝ kəɾ əv ɡɪvən.

Bending, Perrin untied the rag around the pegged man's mouth and tugged the wad from between his teeth. He just managed to snatch his hand back from a snap as vicious as any Stayer could have given.

ɪmiɾiətli, ði ilmən θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ ɪn ə dip, klɪɹ vɔɪs:

Immediately, the Aielman threw back his head and began to sing in a deep, clear voice:

"wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; waɪl ðə sʌn klaɪmz haɪ.

"Wash the spears; while the sun climbs high.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; waɪl ðə sʌn fɔlz loʊ.

Wash the spears; while the sun falls low.

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; hu fɪɹz tə daɪ?

Wash the spears; who fears to die?

wɑʃ ðə spɪɹz; noʊ wʌn aɪ noʊ!"

Wash the spears; no one I know!"

mæsiməz læftɝ ɹoʊz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə sɪŋɪŋ. pɛɹɪnz hækəlz ɹoʊz, tu. hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝd mæsimə læf bɪfɔɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzən saʊnd.

Masema's laughter rose in the middle of the singing. Perrin's hackles rose, too. He had never heard Masema laugh before. It was not a pleasant sound.

hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə luz ə fɪŋɡɝ, soʊ hi pʊld ɪz æks aʊɾ ʌv ɪts bɛlt lup ən kɛɹfəli juz ðə tɑp ə ði æks hɛɾ əɡɛns ðə mænz tʃɪn tə pʊʃ ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt. aɪz ðə kʌlɝ ə ðə skaɪ lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ə sʌn-dɑɹk feɪs, ʌnəfɹeɪd. ðə mæn smaɪld. "aɪ doʊn æsk jə tə bɪtʃɹeɪ jəɹ pipəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hɪz θɹoʊt hɝt wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ ə kipɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs stɛɾi. "ju ʃeɪɾoʊ kæptʃɝd səm wɪmən. ɔl aɪ wɑnə noʊ ɪz haʊ tə ɡɛɾ əm bæk. wʌn ɪz neɪm feɪl. ʃiz əz tɔl əz wʌn ə jəɹ wɪmən, wɪð dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz, ə stʃɹɔŋ noʊz ən ə boʊl maʊð. ə bjuɾəfəl wʊmən. jud ɹɪmɛmbɝ hɝ, ɪf jə hæd sin hɝ. hæv ju?" pʊlɪŋ ði æks əweɪ, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd.

He did not want to lose a finger, so he pulled his axe out of its belt loop and carefully used the top of the axe head against the man's chin to push his mouth shut. Eyes the color of the sky looked up at him out of a sun-dark face, unafraid. The man smiled. "I don't ask you to betray your people," Perrin said. His throat hurt with the effort of keeping his voice steady. "You Shaido captured some women. All I want to know is how to get them back. One is named Faile. She's as tall as one of your women, with dark tilted eyes, a strong nose and a bold mouth. A beautiful woman. You'd remember her, if you had seen her. Have you?" Pulling the axe away, he straightened.

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛɾ ən bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ əɡɛn, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm pɛɹɪn. ɪt wɑz ə dʒɑli sɔŋ, wɪð ðə ɹɑlɪkɪŋ saʊn ʌv ə dæns:

The Shaido stared at him for a moment, then raised his head and began to sing again, never taking his eyes from Perrin. It was a jolly song, with the rollicking sound of a dance:

"aɪ wʌns mɛɾ ə mæn u wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm hoʊm.

"I once met a man who was far from home.

hɪz aɪz wɝ jɛloʊ ən ɪz wɪts wɝ stoʊn.

His eyes were yellow and his wits were stone.

hi æsk mi tə hoʊl smoʊk ɪn maɪ hænd, ən sɛɾ i kəd ʃoʊ mi ə wɔɾɝi lænd.

He asked me to hold smoke in my hand, and said he could show me a watery land.

hi pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ɪz fiɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən sɛɾ i kəd dæns laɪk ə wʊmən fɛɹ.

He put his head in the ground and his feet in the air, and said he could dance like a woman fair.

hi sɛɾ i kəd stæn tɪl i tɝn tə stoʊn.

He said he could stand till he turned to stone.

wən aɪ blɪŋk maɪ aɪz, hi wɑz ɡɔn."

When I blinked my eyes, he was gone."

lɛɾɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɔl bæk, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʃʌkəld, dip ən ɹɪtʃ. hi cʊɾə bɪn laʊnʒɪŋ əɾ iz ɑn ə fɛðɝ bɛd. "ɪf. . . . ɪf jə kæn də ðɪs," ɛɹæm sɛd dɛspɝətli, "ðɛn ɡoʊ əweɪ. əl hɛlp si tə ɪt."

Letting his head fall back, the Shaido chuckled, deep and rich. He could have been lounging at ease on a feather bed. "If. . . . If you can't do this," Aram said desperately, "then go away. I'll help see to it."

wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət ðə feɪsəz ɝaʊn hɪm.

What had to be done. Perrin looked at the faces around him.

ɑɹɡændə, skaʊlɪŋ wɪð heɪtʃɹəd, əɾ ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, naʊ. mæsimə, stɪŋkɪŋ ə mædnəs ən fɪld wɪð ə skɔɹnfəl heɪt. jə mʌs bi wɪlɪŋ ən eɪbəl tə hɝɾ ə stoʊn. ɛdʒɹə, hɝ feɪs əz ənɹiɾəbəl əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪz, ɑɹmz foʊldəd kɑmli bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts. ivən ʃeɪɾoʊ noʊ haʊ tə ɛmbɹeɪs peɪn. ɪɾəl teɪk deɪz. səlɪn, ðə skɑɹ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃik stɪl peɪl ɑn əɹ lɛðɝi skɪn, hɝ ɡeɪz lɛvəl ən əɹ sɛn ɪmplækəbəl. ðəl jil sloʊli ən əz lɪɾəl əz pɑsəbəl. bɹəleɪn, smɛlɪŋ ə dʒʌdʒmənt, ə ɹulɝ u hæd sɛntəns mɛn tə dɛθ ən nɛvɝ lɔst ə naɪts slip. wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn.

Arganda, scowling with hatred, at him as much as the Shaido, now. Masema, stinking of madness and filled with a scornful hate. You must be willing and able to hurt a stone. Edarra, her face as unreadable as the Aes Sedai's, arms folded calmly beneath her breasts. Even Shaido know how to embrace pain. It will take days. Sulin, the scar across her cheek still pale on her leathery skin, her gaze level and her scent implacable. They will yield slowly and as little as possible. Berelain, smelling of judgment, a ruler who had sentenced men to death and never lost a night's sleep. What had to be done.

wɪlɪŋ ən eɪbəl tə hɝɾ ə stoʊn. ɛmbɹeɪs peɪn. oʊ, laɪt, feɪl.

Willing and able to hurt a stone. Embrace pain. Oh, Light, Faile.

ði æks wɑz əz laɪɾ əz ə fɛðɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænd, ən keɪm daʊn laɪk ə hæmɝ ɑn ði ænvəl, ðə hɛvi bleɪd ʃɪɹɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz lɛft ɹɪst.

The axe was as light as a feather rising in his hand, and came down like a hammer on the anvil, the heavy blade shearing through the Shaido's left wrist.

ðə mæn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn peɪn, ðən ɹɪɹɾ ʌp kənvʌlsɪvli wɪð ə snɑɹl, dɪlɪbɝətli spɹeɪɪŋ ðə blʌd ðət ɡtəd fɹəm ɪz ɹɪst əkɹɔs pɛɹɪnz feɪs.

The man grunted in pain, then reared up convulsively with a snarl, deliberately spraying the blood that gouted from his wrist across Perrin's face.

"hil hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, stɛpɪŋ bæk. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə waɪp ɪz feɪs. ðə blʌd wɑz sipɪŋ ɪndə hɪz bɪɹd. hi fɛl hɑloʊ. hi kəd nɑɾ əv lɪftəd ði æks əɡɛn ɪf i hæd tə fəɹ ɪz laɪf.

"Heal him," Perrin said to the Aes Sedai, stepping back. He did not try to wipe his face. The blood was seeping into his beard. He felt hollow. He could not have lifted the axe again if he had to for his life.

"ɑɹ jə mæd?" mɑsʊɝi sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli. "wi kænɑt ɡɪv ðə mæn bæk ɪz hænd!"

"Are you mad?" Masuri said angrily. "We cannot give the man back his hand!"

"aɪ sɛd, hil hɪm!" hi ɡɹaʊld.

"I said, Heal him!" he growled.

siɑnɪd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi muvɪŋ, ðoʊ, lɪftɪŋ əɹ skɝts tə ɡlaɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊn ən nil ət ðə mænz hɛd. hi wɑz baɪɾɪŋ əɾ ɪz sɛvɝd ɹɪst, tʃɹaɪɪŋ fjuɾɪlli tə stɛm ðə floʊ ʌv blʌd wɪð ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz tiθ. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪɹ ɪn ɪz aɪz. əɹ ɪn ɪz smɛl. nʌn.

Seonid was already moving, though, lifting her skirts to glide across the ground and kneel at the man's head. He was biting at his severed wrist, trying futilely to stem the flow of blood with the pressure of his teeth. But there was no fear in his eyes. Or in his smell. None.

siɑnɪd ɡɹɪp ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz hɛd, ən sʌɾənli hi kənvʌlsd əɡɛn, flɪŋɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm aʊt waɪldli.

Seonid gripped the Shaido's head, and suddenly he convulsed again, flinging his arm out wildly.

ðə spɹeɪ ʌv blʌd dwɪndəld əz i dʒɝkt, ən wɑz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ i slʌmp bæk tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɡɹeɪ-feɪst. ənstɛɾəli, hi ɹeɪz ðə stʌmp ə hɪz lɛft ɑɹm tə lʊk ət ðə smuð skɪn ðət naʊ kʌvɝd ði ɛnd. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə skɑɹ, pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt si ɪt. ðə mæn bɛɹd tiθ ət hɪm. hi stɪl dɪd nɑt smɛl əfɹeɪd.

The spray of blood dwindled as he jerked, and was gone before he slumped back to the ground, gray-faced. Unsteadily, he raised the stump of his left arm to look at the smooth skin that now covered the end. If there was a scar, Perrin could not see it. The man bared teeth at him. He still did not smell afraid.

siɑnɪd slʌmpt, tu, əz ɪf ʃi hæd stʃɹeɪn tə hɝ lɪmət. ælhæɹə ən wɪntɝ tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ən ʃi weɪvd əm əweɪ, ɹaɪzɪŋ baɪ hɝsɛlf wɪð ə hɛvi saɪ. "aɪv bɪn toʊl jə kən hoʊld aʊt fəɹ deɪz ən stɪl seɪ nɛks tə nʌθɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs saʊndəd tu laʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. "aɪ doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ jə tə ʃoʊ haʊ tʌf jə ɑɹ, əɹ haʊ bɹeɪv. aɪ noʊ jəɹ bɹeɪv ən tʌf. bʌt maɪ waɪfs bɪn ə pɹɪznɝ tu lɔŋ. jəl bi sɛpɝeɪɾəd ən æskt əbaʊt səm wɪmən. wɛðɝ juv sin əm ən wɛɹ.

Seonid slumped, too, as if she had strained to her limit. Alharra and Wynter took a step forward, and she waved them away, rising by herself with a heavy sigh. "I've been told you can hold out for days and still say next to nothing," Perrin said. His voice sounded too loud in his ears. "I don't have time for you to show how tough you are, or how brave. I know you're brave and tough. But my wife's been a prisoner too long. You'll be separated and asked about some women. Whether you've seen them and where.

ðæts ɔl aɪ wɑnə noʊ. ðɛɹəl bi noʊ hɑt koʊlz əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls; dʒʌs kwɛstʃənz. bʌɾ ɪf ɛnibəɾi ɹəfjuzəz tə ænsɝ, əɹ ɪf jəɹ ænsɝz ɑɹ tu dɪfɹənt, ðən ɛvɹibɑɾi luzəz sʌmθɪŋ." hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ðəɾ i kəd lɪf ði æks æftɝ ɔl. ðə bleɪd wɑz smɪɹd wɪð ɹɛd.

That's all I want to know. There'll be no hot coals or anything else; just questions. But if anybody refuses to answer, or if your answers are too different, then everybody loses something." He was surprised to find that he could lift the axe after all. The blade was smeared with red.

"tu hænz ən tu fit," hi sɛd koʊldli. laɪt, hi saʊndəd laɪk aɪs. hi fɛlt laɪk aɪs tə hɪz boʊnz. "ðæt minz jə ɡɛt fɔɹ tʃænsəz tə ænsɝ ðə seɪm. ən ɪf jə ɔl hoʊld aʊt, aɪ stɪl woʊn kɪl ju. əl faɪn ə vɪlədʒ tə liv jə ɪn, səm pleɪs ðət wɪl lɛt jə bɛɡ, sʌmwɛɹ ðə bɔɪz wɪl tɔs ə kɔɪn tə ðə fɪɹs ilmɛn wɪð noʊ hænz əɹ fit. jə θɪŋk ɑn ɪɾ ən dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ɪts wɝθ kipɪŋ maɪ waɪf fɹəm mi."

"Two hands and two feet," he said coldly. Light, he sounded like ice. He felt like ice to his bones. "That means you get four chances to answer the same. And if you all hold out, I still won't kill you. I'll find a village to leave you in, some place that will let you beg, somewhere the boys will toss a coin to the fierce Aielmen with no hands or feet. You think on it and decide whether it's worth keeping my wife from me."

ivən mæsimə wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ sin ðə mæn stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð ən æks. wən i tɝn tə ɡoʊ, mæsiməz mɛn ən ðə ɡildænɪn əlaɪk pɑɹɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm əz ðoʊ tə lɛɾ ə hoʊl fɪst ə tʃɹɑləks θɹu. hi faʊn ðə hɛdʒ ə ʃɑɹpən steɪks ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən ðə fɔɹəst ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ soʊ bɪɑnd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ dɝɛkʃən. kæɹiɪŋ ði æks, hi wɔkt əntɪl hjudʒ tʃɹiz sɝaʊndəɾ ɪm ən ðə smɛl ə ðə kæmp wɑz lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ðə smɛl ə blʌɾ i kæɹid wɪð hɪm, ʃɑɹp ən mətælɪk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðæt.

Even Masema was staring at him as if he had never before seen the man standing there with an axe. When he turned to go, Masema's men and the Ghealdanin alike parted in front of him as though to let a whole fist of Trollocs through. He found the hedge of sharpened stakes in front of him, and the forest a hundred paces or so beyond, but he did not change direction. Carrying the axe, he walked until huge trees surrounded him and the smell of the camp was left behind. The smell of blood he carried with him, sharp and metallic. There was no running from that.

hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd haʊ lɔŋ i wɔk θɹu ðə snoʊ. hi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə ʃɑɹpənɪŋ slæn ə ðə bɑɹz ə laɪt ðət slaɪs ðə ʃædoʊz bɪniθ ðə fɔɹəs kænəpi. ðə blʌd wɑz θɪk ɑn ɪz feɪs, ɪn ɪz bɪɹd. bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪ. haʊ mɛni taɪmz hæɾ i sɛɾ i wəd də ɛniθɪŋ tə ɡɛt feɪl bæk? ə mæn dɪd wʌɾ i hæd tə. fəɹ feɪl, ɛniθɪŋ.

He could not have said how long he walked through the snow. He barely noticed the sharpening slant of the bars of light that sliced the shadows beneath the forest canopy. The blood was thick on his face, in his beard. Beginning to dry. How many times had he said he would do anything to get Faile back? A man did what he had to. For Faile, anything.

əbɹʌpli, hi ɹeɪz ði æks bɪhaɪn ɪz hɛɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz ən hɝld ɪɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz i kʊd. ɪt spʌn ɛn oʊvɝ ɛnd, ən slæmd ɪndə ðə θɪk tʃɹʌŋk ʌv ən oʊk wɪð ə sɑləd θkʌŋk. lɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə bɹɛθ ðət sim lɑkt ɪn ɪz lʌŋz, hi sæŋk daʊn ɑn ə ɹʌf stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp ðət stʌk ʌp əz haɪ ən bɹɔɾ əz ə bɛntʃ, ən pʊɾ ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz. "ju kən ʃoʊ jɝsɛlf naʊ, ɛlaɪəs," hi sɛd wɛɹəli. "aɪ kən smɛl jə ðɛɹ." ði ʌðɝ mæn stɛp laɪtli aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz, jɛloʊ aɪz ɡloʊɪŋ feɪnli bɪniθ ðə waɪd bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt. ði il wɝ nɔɪzi, kəmpɛɹd tə hɪm. ədʒʌstɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ naɪf, hi tʊk ə sit bɪsaɪd pɛɹɪn ɑn ði aʊtkɹɑp, bʌt fəɹ ə taɪm i mɪɹli sæt koʊmɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz θɹu ðə ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik bɪɹd ðət fæn əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. hi nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ði æks stʌk ɪn ðə saɪɾ ə ði oʊk.

Abruptly, he raised the axe behind his head in both hands and hurled it as hard as he could. It spun end over end, and slammed into the thick trunk of an oak with a solid thcunk. Letting out a breath that seemed locked in his lungs, he sank down on a rough stone outcrop that stuck up as high and broad as a bench, and put his elbows on his knees. "You can show yourself now, Elyas," he said wearily. "I can smell you there." The other man stepped lightly out of the shadows, yellow eyes glowing faintly beneath the wide brim of his hat. The Aiel were noisy, compared to him. Adjusting his long knife, he took a seat beside Perrin on the outcrop, but for a time he merely sat combing his fingers through the gray-streaked beard that fanned across his chest. He nodded toward the axe stuck in the side of the oak.

"aɪ toʊl jə wʌns tə kip ðət tɪl jə ɡɑt tə laɪk juzɪŋ ɪt tu mʌtʃ. dɪd jə stɑɹt laɪkɪŋ ɪt? bæk ðɛɹ?" pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd hɑɹd. "noʊ! nɑt ðæt! bʌt. . . . " "bʌt wʌt, bɔɪ? aɪ θɪŋk jə ɔlmoʊst əv mæsimə skɛɹd. oʊnli, jə smɛl skɛɹd, tu."

"I told you once to keep that till you got to like using it too much. Did you start liking it? Back there?" Perrin shook his head hard. "No! Not that! But. . . . " "But what, boy? I think you almost have Masema scared. Only, you smell scared, too."

"əbaʊt taɪm i wɑz skɛɹɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ," pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ənkʌmftəbli. səm θɪŋz wɝ hɑɹd tə ɡɪv vɔɪs. meɪbi ɪt wɑz taɪm tə, ðoʊ. "ði æks. aɪ dɪdnt noʊɾəs ɪt, ðə fɝs taɪm; oʊnli lʊkɪŋ bæk. ðət wɑz ðə naɪɾ aɪ mɛt ɡɔl, ən ðə waɪtkloʊks tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ʌs. leɪɾɝ, faɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, aɪ wɑznt ʃʊɹ. bʌt ðɛn, ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, aɪ wɑz. aɪm əfɹeɪɾ ɪn ə bæɾəl, ɛlaɪəs, əfɹeɪɾ ən sæd, kəz meɪbi əl nɛvɝ si feɪl əɡɛn." hɪz hɑɹt klɛntʃt tɪl ɪz tʃɛs hɝt.

"About time he was scared of something," Perrin muttered, shrugging uncomfortably. Some things were hard to give voice. Maybe it was time to, though. "The axe. I didn't notice it, the first time; only looking back. That was the night I met Gaul, and the Whitecloaks tried to kill us. Later, fighting Trollocs in the Two Rivers, I wasn't sure. But then, at Dumai's Wells, I was. I'm afraid in a battle, Elyas, afraid and sad, because maybe I'll never see Faile again." His heart clenched till his chest hurt.

feɪl. "oʊnli. . . . aɪv hɝd ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil tɔk əbaʊt haʊ ɪɾ ɪz, hoʊldɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðeɪ seɪ ðeɪ fil mɔɹ əlaɪv. aɪm tu fɹaɪɾənd tə spɪt, ɪn ə bæɾəl, bʌɾ aɪ fil mɔɹ əlaɪv ðən ɛni taɪm ɪksɛpt wən aɪm hoʊldɪŋ feɪl. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ kəd stæn ɪɾ ɪf aɪ keɪm tə fil ðət weɪ əbaʊt wʌɾ aɪ dʒʌs dɪd bæk ðɛɹ. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk feɪl wəɾ əv mi bæk ɪf aɪ keɪm tə ðæt." ɛlaɪəs snɔɹɾɪd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk juv ðəɾ ɪn ju, bɔɪ. lɪsən, deɪnʒɝ teɪks dɪfɹən mɛn ɪn dɪfɹənt weɪz. səm ɑɹ koʊld əz klɑkwɝk, bʌt jə nɛvɝ stʃɹʌk mi əz ðə koʊl sɔɹt. wən jəɹ hɑɹt stɑɹts paʊndɪŋ, ɪt hits jəɹ blʌd. stænz tə ɹizən ɪt haɪɾənz jəɹ sɛnsɪz, tu. meɪks jə əwɛɹ.

Faile. "Only. . . . I've heard Grady and Neald talk about how it is, holding the One Power. They say they feel more alive. I'm too frightened to spit, in a battle, but I feel more alive than any time except when I'm holding Faile. I don't think I could stand it if I came to feel that way about what I just did back there. I don't think Faile would have me back if I came to that." Elyas snorted. "I don't think you have that in you, boy. Listen, danger takes different men in different ways. Some are cold as clockwork, but you never struck me as the cold sort. When your heart starts pounding, it heats your blood. Stands to reason it heightens your senses, too. Makes you aware.

meɪbi jəl daɪ ɪn ə fju mɪnəts, meɪbi ɪn ə hɑɹtbit, bʌt jəɹ nɑt dɛd naʊ, ən jə noʊ ɪt fɹəm jəɹ tiθ tə jəɹ toʊneɪlz. dʒʌs ðə weɪ θɪŋz ɑɹ. dʌzn min jə laɪk ɪt."

Maybe you'll die in a few minutes, maybe in a heartbeat, but you're not dead now, and you know it from your teeth to your toenails. Just the way things are. Doesn't mean you like it."

"aɪ wəd laɪk tə bɪliv ðæt," pɛɹɪn sɛd sɪmpli. "lɪv əz lɔŋ əz aɪ hæv," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə dʒɹaɪ vɔɪs, "æn jəl bɪliv. tɪl ðɛn, dʒʌs teɪk ɪt ðəɾ aɪv lɪv lɔŋɡɝ ðən jə hæv, ən aɪv bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ ju."

"I would like to believe that," Perrin said simply. "Live as long as I have," Elyas replied in a dry voice, "and you'll believe. Till then, just take it that I've lived longer than you have, and I've been there before you."

ðə tu ʌv əm sæt lʊkɪŋ ət ði æks. pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə bɪliv. ðə blʌɾ ɑn ɪz æks lʊk blæk, naʊ. blʌd hæd nɛvɝ lʊk soʊ blæk bɪfɔɹ. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn? fɹəm ði æŋɡəl ə ðə laɪt sɪftɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ðə sʌn wɑz fɔlɪŋ. hɪz ɪɹz kɑt ðə kɹʌntʃ ə hʊvz ɪn ðə snoʊ, sloʊli kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, nild ən ɛɹæm əpɪɹd, ðə wʌntaɪm tɪŋkɝ pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt tʃɹæks ən ði æʃəmən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. ɪt wɑz ə klɪɹ tʃɹeɪl, bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, pɛɹɪn wəd nɑɾ əv bɛɾ ɑn nil biɪŋ eɪbəl tə fɑloʊ ɪt. hi wɑz ə sɪɾi mæn. "ɑɹɡændə θɔt wi ɔt tə weɪt tɪl jəɹ blʌd kuld," nil sɛd, linɪŋ ɑn ɪz sæɾəl ən stʌɾiɪŋ pɛɹɪn. "mi, aɪ θɪŋk ɪt kænt ɡɛɾ ɛni kulɝ." hi nɑɾəd, ə tʌtʃ ə sæɾəsfækʃən ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ. hi wɑz əkʌstəm tə pipəl biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ə hɪm, kəz ə hɪz blæk koʊɾ ən wʌɾ ɪt ɹɛpɹəzɛntəd. "ðeɪ tɔkt," ɛɹæm sɛd, "æn ðeɪ ɔl ɡeɪv ðə seɪm ænsɝz." hɪz skaʊl sɛɾ i dɪd nɑt laɪk ði ænsɝz. "aɪ θɪŋk ðə θɹɛɾ ə livɪŋ əm tə bɛɡ fɹaɪɾənd əm mɔɹ ðən jəɹ æks. bʌt ðeɪ seɪ ðeɪv nɛvɝ sin ðə leɪɾi feɪl. əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz.

The two of them sat looking at the axe. Perrin wanted to believe. The blood on his axe looked black, now. Blood had never looked so black before. How long had it been? From the angle of the light sifting through the trees, the sun was falling. His ears caught the crunch of hooves in the snow, slowly coming toward him. Minutes later, Neald and Aram appeared, the onetime Tinker pointing out tracks and the Asha'man shaking his head impatiently. It was a clear trail, but in truth, Perrin would not have bet on Neald being able to follow it. He was a city man. "Arganda thought we ought to wait till your blood cooled," Neald said, leaning on his saddle and studying Perrin. "Me, I think it can't get any cooler." He nodded, a touch of satisfaction around his mouth. He was accustomed to people being afraid of him, because of his black coat and what it represented. "They talked," Aram said, "and they all gave the same answers." His scowl said he did not like the answers. "I think the threat of leaving them to beg frightened them more than your axe. But they say they've never seen the Lady Faile. Or any of the others.

wi kəd tʃɹaɪ ðə koʊlz əɡɛn. ðeɪ maɪt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛn."

We could try the coals again. They might remember then."

dɪɾ i saʊn iɡɝ? tə faɪn feɪl, əɹ tə juz ðə koʊlz? ɛlaɪəs ɡɹɪməst. "ðeɪl dʒʌst ɡɪv jə bæk ði ænsɝz juv ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən ðɛm, naʊ. tɛl jə wʌt jə wɑnə hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz ə smɔl tʃæns, ɛniweɪ. ðɛɹz θaʊzənz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ ən θaʊzənz ə pɹɪznɝz. ə mæn kəd lɪv ɪz hoʊl laɪf əmʌŋ ðət mɛni pipəl ən nɛvɝ mit mɔɹ ðən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ." "ðɛn wɪv tə kɪl ðɛm," ɛɹæm sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "səlɪn sɛd ðə meɪɾənz meɪd ʃʊɹ tə teɪk əm wən ðeɪ hæd noʊ wɛpənz, soʊ ðeɪ kəd bi kwɛstʃənd. ðeɪ woʊn dʒʌst sɛɾəl daʊn tə bi ɡeɪʃeɪn. ɪf ivən wʌn ɪskeɪps, hi kən lɛt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ noʊ wɝ hɪɹ. ðən ðəl bi kʌmɪŋ æftɝ ʌs." pɛɹɪnz dʒɔɪns fɛlt ɹʌstəd, eɪkɪŋ əz i stʊɾ ʌp. hi kəd nɑt dʒʌs lɛt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ɡoʊ. "ðeɪ kən bi ɡɑɹɾəd, ɛɹæm." heɪs hæɾ ɔlmoʊs lɔst ɪm feɪl kəmplitli, ən i hæd bɪn heɪsti əɡɛn. heɪsti.

Did he sound eager? To find Faile, or to use the coals? Elyas grimaced. "They'll just give you back the answers you've already given them, now. Tell you what you want to hear. It was a small chance, anyway. There's thousands of Shaido and thousands of prisoners. A man could live his whole life among that many people and never meet more than a few hundred to remember." "Then we have to kill them," Aram said grimly. "Sulin said the Maidens made sure to take them when they had no weapons, so they could be questioned. They won't just settle down to be gai'shain. If even one escapes, he can let the Shaido know we're here. Then they'll be coming after us." Perrin's joints felt rusted, aching as he stood up. He could not just let the Shaido go. "They can be guarded, Aram." Haste had almost lost him Faile completely, and he had been hasty again. Hasty.

sətʃ ə maɪld wɝd fəɹ kʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə mænz hænd. ən tə noʊ pɝpəs. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk kɛɹfəli ən muv kɛɹfəli. hi hæd tə θɪŋk naʊ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi θɔt hɝt. feɪl wɑz lɔst ɪn ə si ʌv waɪt-klæd pɹɪznɝz. "meɪbi ʌðɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn wəd noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz," hi mʌɾɝd, tɝnɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp. bʌt haʊ tə pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ɛni ʌv ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz ɡeɪʃeɪn? ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ əlaʊɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə kæmp ɪksɛpt ʌndɝ ɡɑɹd. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðæt, bɔɪ?" ɛlaɪəs æskt.

Such a mild word for cutting off a man's hand. And to no purpose. He had always tried to think carefully and move carefully. He had to think now, but every thought hurt. Faile was lost in a sea of white-clad prisoners. "Maybe other gai'shain would know where she is," he muttered, turning back toward the camp. But how to put his hands on any of the Shaido's gai'shain? They were never allowed outside the camp except under guard. "What about that, boy?" Elyas asked.

pɛɹɪn nu wʌɾ i mɛnt wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ. ði æks. "liv ɪt fəɹ huɛvɝ faɪnz ɪt." hɪz vɔɪs tɝn hɑɹʃ. "meɪbi səm ful ɡlimən wɪl meɪk ə stɔɹi aʊɾ ʌv ɪt." hi stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, nɛvɝ lʊkɪŋ bæk. wɪð ɪts ɛmpti lup, ðə θɪk bɛlt ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst wɑz tu laɪt. ɔl tə noʊ pɝpəs.

Perrin knew what he meant without looking. The axe. "Leave it for whoever finds it." His voice turned harsh. "Maybe some fool gleeman will make a story out of it." He strode away toward the camp, never looking back. With its empty loop, the thick belt around his waist was too light. All to no purpose.

θɹi deɪz leɪɾɝ ðə kɑɹts ɹɪtɝn fɹəm soʊ hæbɝ, hɛvi leɪɾən, ən beɪlwɝ ɛntɝd pɛɹɪnz tɛnt wɪð ə tɔl ənʃeɪvən mæn, wɛɹɪŋ ə dɝɾi wʊlən koʊɾ ən ə sɔɹd ðət lʊk mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ kɛɹd fɔɹ. ət fɝst, pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪm bɪhaɪn ən əntʃɹɪmd mʌnθs ɡɹoʊθ ə bɪɹd. ðən i kɑt ðə mænz sɛnt. "aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə si jə əɡɛn," hi sɛd. beɪlwɝ blɪŋkt, əz mʌtʃ əz ə ɡæsp ə stɑɹɾəlmənt fɹəm ɛniwʌn ɛls. daʊtləs ðə bɝd-laɪk lɪɾəl mæn hæd bɪn lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə pɹɪzɛntɪŋ ə sɝpɹaɪz.

Three days later the carts returned from So Habor, heavy laden, and Balwer entered Perrin's tent with a tall unshaven man, wearing a dirty woolen coat and a sword that looked much better cared for. At first, Perrin did not recognize him behind an untrimmed month's growth of beard. Then he caught the man's scent. "I never expected to see you again," he said. Balwer blinked, as much as a gasp of startlement from anyone else. Doubtless the bird-like little man had been looking forward to presenting a surprise.

"aɪv bɪn sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ . . . fəɹ meɪaɪɡdɪn," tɑlænvɝ sɛd ɹʌfli, "bʌt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ muv fæstɝ ðən aɪ kʊd. mæstɝ beɪlwɝ sɛz jə noʊ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz."

"I've been searching for . . . for Maighdin," Tallanvor said roughly, "but the Shaido moved faster than I could. Master Balwer says you know where she is."

beɪlwɝ ɡeɪv ðə jʌŋɡɝ mæn ə ʃɑɹp lʊk, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn əz dʒɹaɪ ən ɪmoʊʃənləs əz ɪz sɛnt. "mæstɝ tɑlænvɝ ɹitʃt soʊ hæbɝ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ aɪ lɛft, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪt wɑz ðə mɛɹəs tʃæns ðəɾ aɪ ɪnkaʊntɝd hɪm. bʌt pɝhæps ə fɔɹtʃənət tʃæns. hi meɪ hæv səm ælaɪz fəɹ ju. əl lɛɾ ɪm tɛl ɪt.". tɑlænvɝ fɹaʊn əɾ ɪz buts ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Balwer gave the younger man a sharp look, but his voice remained as dry and emotionless as his scent. "Master Tallanvor reached So Habor just before I left, my Lord. It was the merest chance that I encountered him. But perhaps a fortunate chance. He may have some allies for you. I will let him tell it.". Tallanvor frowned at his boots and said nothing.

"ælaɪz?" pɛɹɪn pɹɑmptəd. "nʌθɪŋ lɛs ðən ən ɑɹmi wɪl bi mʌtʃ jus, bʌɾ əl teɪk ɛni eɪd jə kən bɹɪŋ." tɑlænvɝ lʊkt ət beɪlwɝ, hu ɹɪtɝn ə hæf baʊ ən ə blænli ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ smaɪl.

"Allies?" Perrin prompted. "Nothing less than an army will be much use, but I'll take any aid you can bring." Tallanvor looked at Balwer, who returned a half bow and a blandly encouraging smile.

ði ənʃeɪvən mæn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "fɪftin θaʊzən sintʃæn, nɪɹ ɪnʌf. moʊst ɑɹ tæɹɑbənɝz, æktʃəli , bʌt ðeɪ ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ sintʃæn bænɝz. ænd. . . . ðeɪv hæv ət list ə dʌzən deɪmeɪn." hɪz vɔɪs kwɪkənd wɪð ɝdʒənsi, ə nid tə fɪnɪʃ bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn kəd kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "aɪ noʊ ɪts laɪk teɪkɪŋ hɛlp fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, bʌt ðəɹ hʌntɪŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, tu, ən aɪd teɪk ðə dɑɹk wʌnz hɛlp tə fɹi meɪaɪɡdɪn." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ðə tu mɛn, tɑlænvɝ nɝvəsli θʌmɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, beɪlwɝ laɪk ə spɛɹoʊ weɪɾɪŋ tə si wɪtʃ weɪ ə kɹɪkət wəd hɑp. sintʃæn. ən deɪmeɪn. jɛs, ðət wəd bi laɪk teɪkɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz hɛlp. "sɪt daʊn ən tɛl mi əbaʊt ðiz sintʃæn," hi sɛd.

The unshaven man drew a deep breath. "Fifteen thousand Seanchan, near enough. Most are Taraboners, actually, but they ride under Seanchan banners. And. . . . And they have at least a dozen damane." His voice quickened with urgency, a need to finish before Perrin could cut him off. "I know it's like taking help from the Dark One, but they're hunting the Shaido, too, and I'd take the Dark One's help to free Maighdin." For a moment, Perrin stared at the two men, Tallanvor nervously thumbing his sword hilt, Balwer like a sparrow waiting to see which way a cricket would hop. Seanchan. And damane. Yes, that would be like taking the Dark One's help. "Sit down and tell me about these Seanchan," he said.

tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt

CHAPTER 28

eɪ klʌstɝ ə ɹoʊzbʊdz fɹəm ðə deɪ ðeɪ lɛft ɛbu dɑɹ, tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ən mæɡnɪfəsən dɪspleɪ ʌv mɑɹvəlz ən wʌndɝz wɑz ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz bæɾ əz mæts dɑɹkəs θɔts hæd meɪɾ ɪt. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɪt ɹeɪn ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi deɪ fəɹ ə fju aʊɝz ən wʌns fəɹ θɹi deɪz ɹʌnɪŋ, koʊld wɪntɝ ɹeɪn ɪn daʊnpɔɹz lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə snoʊ ən aɪsi dʒɹɪzəlz ðət sloʊli soʊkt ə koʊt θɹu ən lɛf jə ʃɪvɝɪŋ bɪfɔɹ jə nu ɪt. wɔɾɝ ɹæn ɔf ðə hɑɹd-pækt ɹoʊɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn peɪvd ɪn stoʊn, livɪŋ ət wɝst ə θɪn slɪk ə mʌd, bʌt ðət lɔŋ tʃɹeɪn ʌv wæɡənz ən hɔɹsəz ən pipəl kʌvɝd lɪɾəl ɪnʌf ɡɹaʊnd wən ðə sʌn ʃoʊn. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ðə ʃoʊfoʊk hæd bɪn ɔl iɡɝnəs tə liv ðə sɪɾi wɛɹ laɪtnɪŋ sæŋk ʃɪps ɪn ðə naɪɾ ən stʃɹeɪnʒ mɝɾɝz hæɾ ɛvɹiwʌn lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ə dʒɛləs sintʃæn noʊbəlmən u wəd bi hʌntɪŋ ɪz waɪf fjʊɹiəsli ən maɪt teɪk aʊɾ ɪz æŋɡɝ ɑn ɛniwʌn əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð spɪɹəɾɪŋ əɹ aʊɾ əɹ ə hɪz klʌtʃəz. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ðeɪ pɹɛst əhɛɾ əz fæst əz ðə hɔɹsəz kəd pʊl ðə wæɡənz, ɝdʒɪŋ ði ænəməlz fəɹ ə kwɪkɝ stɛp, ənʌðɝ maɪl. bʌɾ ɛvɹi maɪl sim tə meɪk əm fil ðət mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm deɪnʒɝ, ðət mʌtʃ seɪfɝ, ən baɪ ðə fɝst æftɝnun. . . .

A Cluster of Rosebuds From the day they left Ebou Dar, traveling with Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvels and Wonders was every bit as bad as Mat's darkest thoughts had made it. For one thing, it rained almost every day for a few hours and once for three days running, cold winter rain in downpours little short of snow and icy drizzles that slowly soaked a coat through and left you shivering before you knew it. Water ran off the hard-packed road as if it had been paved in stone, leaving at worst a thin slick of mud, but that long train of wagons and horses and people covered little enough ground when the sun shone. In the beginning, the showfolk had been all eagerness to leave the city where lightning sank ships in the night and strange murders had everyone looking over their shoulders, to be away from a jealous Seanchan nobleman who would be hunting his wife furiously and might take out his anger on anyone associated with spiriting her out her of his clutches. In the beginning, they pressed ahead as fast as the horses could pull the wagons, urging the animals for a quicker step, another mile. But every mile seemed to make them feel that much farther from danger, that much safer, and by the first afternoon. . . .

"hæv tə teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə hɔɹsəz," lukə ɪkspleɪnd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tim ənhɪtʃt fɹəm ɪz ɹədɪkjələsli peɪntəd wæɡən ən lɛɾ əweɪ tə ðə hɔɹslaɪnz θɹu ə laɪt dʒɹɪzəl. ðə sʌn stɪl sæt lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ daʊn tə ðə hɝaɪzən, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɹeɪ tɛnʒɹəlz wɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə smoʊk hoʊlz ə tɛns ən ðə mɛɾəl tʃɪmniz ə ðə bɑks-laɪk lɪvɪŋ wæɡənz. "noʊbɑdiz tʃeɪsɪŋ ʌs, ən ɪts ə lɔŋ weɪ tə luɡɹd. ɡʊd hɔɹsəz ɑɹ hɑɹd tə kʌm baɪ, ən ɪkspɛnsɪv." lukə ɡeɪv ə saʊɝ fɹaʊn ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. mɛnʃən ʌv ɪkspɛns ɔlweɪz saʊɝd hɪm. hi wɑz taɪt wɪð ə pɛni, ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ɪz waɪf wɑz kənsɝnd. "nɑt mɛni pleɪsəz bɪtwin hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wɝθ stɑpɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə deɪ. moʊs vɪlədʒəz woʊn pɹəvaɪɾ ə fʊl kɹaʊɾ ivən ɪf ðə hoʊl pɑpjəleɪʃən tɝnz aʊt, ən jə kən nɛvɝ tɛl haʊ ə taʊn wɪl bi əntɪl jə sɛɾ ʌp. jəɹ nɑt peɪɪŋ mi ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ʌp wʌɾ aɪ kən ɝn, ðoʊ." hɪtʃɪŋ ɪz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kɹɪmzən kloʊk kloʊsɝ əɡɛns ðə dæmp, hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ təwɔɹɾ ɪz wæɡən. ðə smɛl ə sʌmθɪŋ bɪɾɝ dʒɹɪftəd θɹu ðə laɪt ɹeɪn. mæt wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i wəd wɑnə iɾ ɛniθɪŋ lukəz waɪf kʊkt. "jɔɹ sɝɾən noʊbɑdi ɪz tʃeɪsɪŋ ʌs, ɹaɪt, kɔθən?" ɪɹɪɾəbli tʌɡɪŋ ɪz wʊlən kæp loʊɝ, mæt stɔkt əweɪ θɹu ðə bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd spɹɔl ə tɛns ən wæɡənz ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɪz tiθ. nɑt peɪɪŋ ɪnʌf? fəɹ wʌɾ i hæɾ ɔfɝd, lukə ʃʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə ɹʌn ɪz ænəməlz ɔl ðə weɪ tə luɡɹd. wɛl, nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɹʌn - hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə kɪl hɔɹsəz, æftɝ ɔl - bʌt ðət pʌft-ʌp poʊpənʒ ʃʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə blʌɾi pʊʃ hɑɹd.

"Have to take care of the horses," Luca explained, watching the team unhitched from his ridiculously painted wagon and led away to the horselines through a light drizzle. The sun still sat little more than halfway down to the horizon, but already gray tendrils were rising from the smoke holes of tents and the metal chimneys of the box-like living wagons. "Nobody's chasing us, and it's a long way to Lugard. Good horses are hard to come by, and expensive." Luca gave a sour frown and shook his head. Mention of expense always soured him. He was tight with a penny, except where his wife was concerned. "Not many places between here and there worth stopping more than a day. Most villages won't provide a full crowd even if the whole population turns out, and you can never tell how a town will be until you set up. You're not paying me enough to give up what I can earn, though." Hitching his embroidered crimson cloak closer against the damp, he glanced over his shoulder toward his wagon. The smell of something bitter drifted through the light rain. Mat was not sure he would want to eat anything Luca's wife cooked. "You're certain nobody is chasing us, right, Cauthon?" Irritably tugging his woolen cap lower, Mat stalked away through the brightly colored sprawl of tents and wagons grinding his teeth. Not paying enough? For what he had offered, Luca should have been willing to run his animals all the way to Lugard. Well, not exactly run - he did not want to kill horses, after all - but that puffed-up popinjay should have been willing to bloody push hard.

nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm lukəz wæɡən, tʃəl veɪnɪn wɑz siɾəd ɑn ə θɹiləɡd stul ðəɾ i oʊvɝlæpt, stɝɪŋ səm sɔɹɾ ə dɑɹk stu ɪn ə smɔl kɛɾəl ðət hʌŋ oʊvɝ ə smɔl faɪɝ. ɹeɪn dʒɹɪpt ɪndə ðə kɛɾəl fɹəm ðə dʒɹupɪŋ bɹɪm ə hɪz hæt, bʌt ðə fæt mæn dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs, əɹ kɛɹ. ɡɔɹɾɝən ən fɝdʒɪn, tu ʌv ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, ɡɹʌmbəl kɝsɪz əz ðeɪ dʒɹoʊv pɛɡz ɪndə ðə mʌɾi ɡɹaʊn fəɹ ðə ɡaɪ ɹoʊps ə ðə dɝɾi-bɹaʊn kænvəs tɛn ðeɪ ʃɛɹd wɪð hɑɹnən ən mɛtwɪn. ən wɪð veɪnɪn, tu, bʌt veɪnɪn pəzɛst skɪlz ðəɾ i kənsɪɾɝd pʊɾ ɪm əbʌv ɹeɪzɪŋ tɛns, ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz əɡɹid wɪð oʊnli ə lɪɾəl ɹɪlʌktəns. veɪnɪn wɑz ən ɪkspɪɹiəns fɛɹiɝ, bʌt mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, hi wɑz ðə bɛs tʃɹækɝ ən ðə bɛs hɔɹsɛθif ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi, ənlaɪkli əz ðət sim tə lʊk ət hɪm, ən jə kəd neɪm ðə kʌntʃɹi jə tʃoʊz.

Not far from Luca's wagon, Chel Vanin was seated on a threelegged stool that he overlapped, stirring some sort of dark stew in a small kettle that hung over a small fire. Rain dripped into the kettle from the drooping brim of his hat, but the fat man did not seem to notice, or care. Gorderan and Fergin, two of the Redarms, grumbled curses as they drove pegs into the muddy ground for the guy ropes of the dirty-brown canvas tent they shared with Harnan and Metwyn. And with Vanin, too, but Vanin possessed skills that he considered put him above raising tents, and the Redarms agreed with only a little reluctance. Vanin was an experienced farrier, but more importantly, he was the best tracker and the best horsethief in the country, unlikely as that seemed to look at him, and you could name the country you chose.

fɝdʒɪn kɑt saɪɾ ə mæt, ən bɪɾ ɔf ən oʊθ əz ɪz hæmɝ mɪs ðə tɛn pɛɡ ən hɪɾ ɪz θʌm. dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə hæmɝ, hi stʌk ðə θʌm ɪn ɪz maʊθ ən skwɑɾɪd ðəɹ kəmpleɪnɪŋ ʃɹɪli ɝaʊn ɪt. "wɝ gɑnə bi aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs ɔl naɪt ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðoʊz wɪmən, maɪ lɔɹd. kæn jə haɪɝ səm ə ðoʊz hɔɹs hænlɝz tə də ðɪs soʊ wi kən ət list steɪ dʒɹaɪ tɪl wɪv tə ɡɛt wɛt?" ɡɔɹɾɝən poʊk fɝdʒɪnz ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ. hi wɑz əz waɪɾ əz fɝdʒɪn wɑz skɪni, ən ə tɛɹən dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ɡɹeɪ aɪz. "hɔɹs hænlɝzəl pʊɾ ʌp ðə tɛn ən stil ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪt ðæts lus, fɝdʒɪn." ənʌðɝ poʊk. "ju wɑnt wʌn ə ðoʊz laɪtfɪŋɝz wɔkɪŋ ɔf wɪð maɪ kɹɔsboʊ, əɹ maɪ sæɾəl? ðæts ə ɡʊd sæɾəl." ə θɝd poʊk nɪɹli pʊʃt fɝdʒɪn oʊvɝ saɪdweɪz. "wi doʊnt ɡɛt ðɪs tɛn ʌp, ən hɑɹnənəl əv əs stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ ɔl naɪt." fɝdʒɪn ɡlaʊɝɾ ən ɡɹʌmbəld, bʌɾ i pɪkt ʌp ɪz hæmɝ, waɪpɪŋ ðə mʌɾ ɔf ɑn ɪz koʊt. hi wɑz ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf soʊlʒɝ, bʌt nɑt vɛɹi bɹaɪt.

Fergin caught sight of Mat, and bit off an oath as his hammer missed the tent peg and hit his thumb. Dropping the hammer, he stuck the thumb in his mouth and squatted there complaining shrilly around it. "We're going to be out in this all night guarding those women, my Lord. Can't you hire some of those horse handlers to do this so we can at least stay dry till we have to get wet?" Gorderan poked Fergin's shoulder with a thick finger. He was as wide as Fergin was skinny, and a Tairen despite his gray eyes. "Horse handlers'll put up the tent and steal everything in it that's loose, Fergin." Another poke. "You want one of those lightfingers walking off with my crossbow, or my saddle? That's a good saddle." A third poke nearly pushed Fergin over sideways. "We don't get this tent up, and Harnan'll have us standing guard all night." Fergin glowered and grumbled, but he picked up his hammer, wiping the mud off on his coat. He was a good enough soldier, but not very bright.

veɪnɪn spæt θɹu ðə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ, dʒʌs mɪsɪŋ ðə kɛɾəl. ðə stu smɛld wʌndɝfəl æftɝ wʌtɛvɝ lətɛl wɑz meɪkɪŋ, bʌt mæt dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑz nɑt gɑnə it hɪɹ, iðɝ. tæpɪŋ ɪz wʊɾən spun ɑn ðə ɹɪm ə ðə kɛɾəl tə klin ɪt, ðə fæt mæn lʊkt ʌp ət mæt θɹu hɛvi-lɪɾɪd aɪz. hɪz ɹaʊn feɪs ɔfən lʊk hæf-əslip, bʌɾ oʊnli ə ful bɪlivd ɪt. "æt ðɪs ɹeɪt, wɪl ɹitʃ luɡɹɾ əbaʊt ði ɛn ə sʌmɝ. ɪf wi ɛvɝ du." "wi wɪl, veɪnɪn," mæt sɛd, mɔɹ kɑnfəɾəntli ðən i fɛlt ət ðə moʊmənt. ðə ɹʌf wʊlən koʊɾ i hæd dɑn dʒɹaɪ ə fju aʊɝz əɡoʊ oʊnli ʃɛd ɹeɪn ɪn spɑts, ən wɔɾɝ wɑz tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə fil kɑnfəɾənt wɪð aɪsi ɹeɪn slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn jəɹ bækboʊn.

Vanin spat through the gap in his teeth, just missing the kettle. The stew smelled wonderful after whatever Latelle was making, but Mat decided he was not going to eat here, either. Tapping his wooden spoon on the rim of the kettle to clean it, the fat man looked up at Mat through heavy-lidded eyes. His round face often looked half-asleep, but only a fool believed it. "At this rate, we'll reach Lugard about the end of summer. If we ever do." "We will, Vanin," Mat said, more confidently than he felt at the moment. The rough woolen coat he had donned dry a few hours ago only shed rain in spots, and water was trickling down his back. It was hard to feel confident with icy rain sliding down your backbone.

"wɪntɝz ɔlmoʊs dʌn. wɪl muv fæstɝ wʌns spɹɪŋ kʌmz. jəl si. kʌm ðə mɪɾəl ə spɹɪŋ, ən wɪl bi ɪn luɡɹd."

"Winter's almost done. We'll move faster once spring comes. You'll see. Come the middle of spring, and we'll be in Lugard."

hi wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ ə ðæt, iðɝ. ðeɪ kʌvɝd noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu liɡz ðət fɝs deɪ, ən æftɝ ðæt, tu ən ə hæf meɪɾ ə ɡʊd deɪ. nɑt mɛni pleɪsəz kəd bi kɔl taʊnz əlɔŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, ə neɪm ðət bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪnʒ vɛɹi kwɪkli əz ðə ʃoʊ kɹɛp nɔɹθ. pipəl kɔld ɪt "ði ɛbu dɑɹ ɹoʊd," əɹ "ðə fɛɹi ɹoʊd," əɹ səmtaɪmz dʒʌst "ðə ɹoʊd," əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli wʌn. bʌt lukə stɑpt əɾ ɛvɹi læs taʊn, ɹil əɹ soʊ-kɔld, wɔld əɹ dʒʌmpt-ʌp vɪlədʒ wɪð sɪks stʃɹits ən ə ɹʌf-peɪvd ɪkskjus fəɹ ə taʊn skwɛɹ. nɪɹ hæf ə deɪ wɛn ɪndə dʒʌst ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə ʃoʊ sɛɾ ʌp ən ðə kænvəs wɔl ɪɹɛktəɾ ɝaʊn ɪt wɪð ðət hjudʒ ɹɛd-lɛɾɝd blu bænɝ hʌŋ əkɹɔs ði ɛntʃɹəns. vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs nɑɾ ɪn lukə tə pæs ʌp ðə tʃæns ʌv ə kɹaʊd. əɹ ðə kɔɪnz ɪn ðɛɹ pɝsɪz. əɹ ðə tʃæns tə flɝɪʃ wʌn ə hɪz bɹaɪt ɹɛd kloʊks ən bæsk ɪn ðɛɹ ædʒəleɪʃən. lukə laɪk ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ðə kɔɪn. ɔlmoʊst.

He was not so sure of that, either. They covered no more than two leagues that first day, and after that, two and a half made a good day. Not many places could be called towns along the Great North Road, a name that began to change very quickly as the show crept north. People called it "the Ebou Dar Road," or "the Ferry Road," or sometimes just "the road," as if there were only one. But Luca stopped at every last town, real or so-called, walled or jumped-up village with six streets and a rough-paved excuse for a town square. Near half a day went into just getting the show set up and the canvas wall erected around it with that huge red-lettered blue banner hung across the entrance. Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show. It was just not in Luca to pass up the chance of a crowd. Or the coins in their purses. Or the chance to flourish one of his bright red cloaks and bask in their adulation. Luca liked that almost as much as the coin. Almost.

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə ðə pɝfɔɹmɝz ən ðə keɪdʒd ænəməlz fɹəm fɑɹ-ɔf lænz wɝ səfɪʃən tə pʊl pipəl. ði ænəməlz fɹəm nɑt soʊ fɑɹ wɝ ɪnʌf, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ; fju hæd bɪn fɑɹ ɪnʌf ɪndə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd tə si ə bɛɹ mʌtʃ lɛs ə laɪən. oʊnli hɛvi ɹeɪn lɛsən ðə kɹaʊd, ən wən ðə ɹeɪn wɑz tu stɪf, ðə dʒʌɡəlɝz ən ækɹəbæts ɹəfjuz tə pɝfɔɹm ɛniweɪ wɪθaʊt səm sɔɹɾ ə kʌvɝɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd.

The strangeness of the performers and the caged animals from far-off lands were sufficient to pull people. The animals from not so far were enough, for that matter; few had been far enough into the countryside to see a bear much less a lion. Only heavy rain lessened the crowd, and when the rain was too stiff, the jugglers and acrobats refused to perform anyway without some sort of covering overhead.

wɪtʃ meɪd lukə stɔk əbaʊɾ ɪn ə sʌlən snɪɾ ən tɔk waɪldli ʌv faɪndɪŋ ɪnʌf kænvəs tɑɹps tə ʃɛltɝ ɛvɹi ækt, əɹ hævɪŋ ə tɛn meɪd lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə hoʊl ði ɪntaɪɝ ʃoʊ. wʌn tɛnt! ðə mæn wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪf nɑt ɡɹændioʊs ɪn ɪz æmbɪʃənz. waɪ nɑɾ ə pæləs ɑn wilz waɪl i wɑz əbaʊɾ ɪt?

Which made Luca stalk about in a sullen snit and talk wildly of finding enough canvas tarps to shelter every act, or having a tent made large enough to hold the entire show. One tent! The man was nothing if not grandiose in his ambitions. Why not a palace on wheels while he was about it?

ɪf lukə ən ðə sloʊ weɪ ðə ʃoʊ muv hæd bɪn ɔl mæt hæd tə wɝi əbaʊt, ðoʊ, hi wʊɾə bɪn ə hæpi mæn. səmtaɪmz, tu əɹ θɹi sloʊ-muvɪŋ tʃɹeɪnz ə sintʃæn sɛtlɝz u hæd ɡɑɾən ən ɝli stɑɹt pæst wɪð ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪnʒli ʃeɪpt, pikt wæɡənz ən ɑd-lʊkɪŋ kæɾəl əɹ ʃip əɹ ɡoʊts bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst wæɡən fɹəm ðə ʃoʊ bɪɡæn tə muv. səmtaɪmz kɑləmz ə sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz oʊvɝtʊk əm əz ðeɪ æmbəld əlɔŋ əɾ ə sloʊ wɔk, ɹæŋks ə mɛn wɛɹɪŋ hɛlməts laɪk hjudʒ ɪnsɛks' hɛdz, stɛpɪŋ aʊt smɑɹtli, ən kɑləmz ə hɔɹsmən wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts peɪntəɾ ɪn stʃɹaɪps. wʌns, ðə ɹaɪɾɝz wɝ ɑn fɔɹm, bɹɑnz-skeɪl kɹitʃɝz laɪk hɔɹs-saɪz kæts. ɪksɛp fəɹ hævɪŋ θɹi aɪz, ɛniweɪ. twɛnti əɹ soʊ ʌv əm sneɪkɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪn ə sɪnwəs loʊp fæstɝ ðən ə hɔɹs kəd tʃɹɑt. niðɝ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz nɔɹ ðɛɹ maʊns ɡeɪv ðə ʃoʊ ə sɛkənd ɡlæns, bʌt ðə ʃoʊz hɔɹsəz wɛnt waɪld əz ðə fɔɹm pæst, skɹimɪŋ ən ɹɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɹeɪsəz. ðə laɪənz ən lɛpɝdz ən bɛɹz ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ðɛɹ keɪdʒɪz, ən ðə pəkjuljɝ dɪɹ flʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛns ðə bɑɹz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fli. ɪt, tʊk aʊɝz tə kwaɪəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ daʊn ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə wæɡənz tə muv əɡɛn, ən lukə ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn hævɪŋ ðə keɪdʒd ænəməlz' skɹeɪps sin tə fɝst. hɪz ænəməlz wɝ ə lɑɹdʒ ɪnvɛsmənt. twaɪs, ɔfəsɝz ɪn θɪn-plum hɛlməts dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɛk ðə wɔɹən fəɹ lukəs hɔɹsəz, ən mæt uz koʊl swɛt ðə saɪz ʌv ɡɹeɪps əntɪl ðeɪ muvd ɑn əɡɛn, sæɾəsfaɪd. əz ðə ʃoʊ kɹɛp nɔɹθ, ðə nʌmbɝz ə sintʃæn ɑn ðə ɹoʊd dwɪndəld, jɛɾ i stɪl swɛɾɪd wən i sɔ ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾi, soʊlʒɝz əɹ sɛtlɝz iðɝ wʌn. meɪbi sjuɹɔθ ɹɪli wɑz kipɪŋ tuɑnz dɪsəpɪɹəns ə sikɹət, bʌt ðə sintʃæn wəd bi sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ hɝ. ɔl ɪt wəd teɪk wɑz wʌn mɛɾəlsəm ɔfəsɝ u æktʃəli  kəmpɛɹd ðə nʌmbɝz ɑn ðə wɔɹənt wɪð ðə nʌmbɝ ə hɔɹsəz. hi wəd sɝtʃ ðə wæɡənz wɪð ə faɪn-tuθ koʊm æftɝ ðæt, fəɹ sɝɾən. dʒʌst wʌn ɔfɪʃəs mldəm u θɔt ðəɹ maɪt bi ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl əmʌŋ ðə dʒʌɡəlɝz ən tʌmblɝz ən kəntɔɹʃənɪsts. hi swɛɾɪd plʌmz! ənfɔɹtʃənətli, nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn hæɾ ə pɹɑpɝ ɹəɡɑɹd fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn skɪnz.

If Luca and the slow way the show moved had been all Mat had to worry about, though, he would have been a happy man. Sometimes, two or three slow-moving trains of Seanchan settlers who had gotten an early start passed with their strangely shaped, peaked wagons and odd-looking cattle or sheep or goats before the first wagon from the show began to move. Sometimes columns of Seanchan soldiers overtook them as they ambled along at a slow walk, ranks of men wearing helmets like huge insects' heads, stepping out smartly, and columns of horsemen with their armor of overlapping plates painted in stripes. Once, the riders were on form, bronze-scaled creatures like horse-sized cats. Except for having three eyes, anyway. Twenty or so of them snaking along in a sinuous lope faster than a horse could trot. Neither the riders nor their mounts gave the show a second glance, but the show's horses went wild as the form passed, screaming and rearing in the traces. The lions and leopards and bears roared in their cages, and the peculiar deer flung themselves against the bars trying to flee. It, took hours to quiet everything down enough for the wagons to move again, and Luca insisted on having the caged animals' scrapes seen to first. His animals were a large investment. Twice, officers in thin-plumed helmets decided to check the warrant for Lucas horses, and Mat oozed cold sweat the size of grapes until they moved on again, satisfied. As the show crept north, the numbers of Seanchan on the road dwindled, yet he still sweated when he saw another party, soldiers or settlers either one. Maybe Suroth really was keeping Tuon's disappearance a secret, but the Seanchan would be searching for her. All it would take was one meddlesome officer who actually compared the numbers on the warrant with the number of horses. He would search the wagons with a fine-tooth comb after that, for certain. Just one officious ml'dam who thought there might be a woman who could channel among the jugglers and tumblers and contortionists. He sweated plums! Unfortunately, not everyone had a proper regard for their own skins.

aʊtsaɪɾ ə flaɪspɛk vɪlədʒ kɔld wisən, ə θætʃ-ɹuf lɪɾəl klʌstɝ ə haʊsəz wɛɹ nɑɾ ivən lukə θɔt tu kɑpɝz kəd bi ʃeɪkən lus, mæt stʊd wɪð ə hɛvi wʊlən kloʊk pʊld ɝaʊn ɪm ɪn ə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɹeɪn ən wɑtʃt ðə θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ stil bæk ɪndə ðə ʃoʊ əz ðə sʌn sɛt. θʌndɝ bumd ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ðeɪ wɝ swɑðd ɪn dɑɹk kloʊks wɪð ðə hʊdz wɛl ʌp, jɛɾ i hæd noʊ daʊts u ðeɪ wɝ. ɪn ðə daʊnpɔɹ, ðeɪ pæst wɪðɪn tɛn fit wɪθaʊt siɪŋ hɪm, bʌt ðə sɪlvɝ mədæljən hæŋɪŋ bɪniθ ɪz ʃɝt wɛn koʊld əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. ət list wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz tʃænəlɪŋ, əɹ hoʊldɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ɛniweɪ. bɝn hɪm, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl θɹi mæɾ əz lunz.

Outside a flyspeck village called Weesin, a thatch-roofed little cluster of houses where not even Luca thought two coppers could be shaken loose, Mat stood with a heavy woolen cloak pulled around him in a driving rain and watched the three Aes Sedai steal back into the show as the sun set. Thunder boomed in the distance. They were swathed in dark cloaks with the hoods well up, yet he had no doubts who they were. In the downpour, they passed within ten feet without seeing him, but the silver medallion hanging beneath his shirt went cold against his chest. At least one of them was channeling, or holding the Power, anyway. Burn him, they were all three mad as loons.

noʊ sunɝ dɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ vænɪʃ əmʌŋ ðə wæɡənz ən tɛns ðən θɹi mɔɹ kloʊkt ʃeɪps əpɪɹd, hɝiɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm. wʌn ə ðiz wɪmən hæɾ ə ʃɑɹpɝ aɪ, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə pɔɪn ət hɪm, bʌt ði ʌðɝz oʊnli pɔzd, ən ðən ðeɪ skɝiɾ æftɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ təɡɛðɝ. hi stɑɹɾəd tə kɝs, ðən lɛft ɪɾ ənʌɾɝd. hi wɑz bɪɑn ðæt. ɪf i neɪm ðə pipəl i wɑntəd wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɛɹ ə sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl maɪt si ðɛm, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə sʌldəm wəd kʌm əbaʊɾ ivən wɪð tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə.

No sooner did the Aes Sedai vanish among the wagons and tents than three more cloaked shapes appeared, hurrying after them. One of these women had a sharper eye, raising a hand to point at him, but the others only paused, and then they scurried after the Aes Sedai together. He started to curse, then left it unuttered. He was beyond that. If he named the people he wanted wandering around where a Seanchan patrol might see them, the Aes Sedai and the sul'dam would come about even with Tuon and Selucia.

"aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt ðeɪ wɑnt?" noʊl sɛd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən mæt ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp ðət lɛɾ ə tɔɹən ə ɹeɪn ɪndə hɪz kaʊl ən daʊn ɪz nɛk. hi wɪʃt ðə nɑbəli oʊl mæn wəd kwɪt snikɪŋ ʌp ɑn hɪm. "aɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪn aʊt," hi mʌɾɝd, dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz kloʊk stʃɹeɪt. hi hɑɹdli nu waɪ hi bɑðɝd. hɪz koʊt wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl dæmp, bʌɾ ɪz lɪnən ʃɝt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi soʊkt.

"I wonder what they want?" Noal said behind him, and Mat gave a jump that let a torrent of rain into his cowl and down his neck. He wished the knobbly old man would quit sneaking up on him. "I intend to find out," he muttered, jerking his cloak straight. He hardly knew why he bothered. His coat was only a little damp, but his linen shirt was already soaked.

ɑdli ɪnʌf, noʊl wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɪð ɪm wən i ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹikt wæɡən wɪð ɪts feɪɾɪŋ waɪtwɑʃ wɛɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən sʌldəm slɛpt. ðə mæn laɪk stɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊz ɪn ɛvɹiwɛɹ. meɪbi hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑz wɛɾ ɪnʌf. blɹɪk ən fɛn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ blæŋkəts bɪniθ ðə wæɡən, əpɛɹənli əblɪviəs tə ɹeɪn əɹ mʌd, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv weɪdʒɝɾ ɑn iðɝ biɪŋ əslip. ɪndid, wʌn sæɾ ʌp əz i skwɛltʃt ʌp tə ðə wæɡən. wɪtʃɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, jɛt mæt kəd fil ðə mænz aɪz. hi dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt, ðoʊ, ən i dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð nɑkɪŋ.

Oddly enough, Noal was no longer with him when he reached the gray-streaked wagon with its fading whitewash where the Aes Sedai and sul'dam slept. The man liked sticking his nose in everywhere. Maybe he had decided he was wet enough. Blaeric and Fen were already wrapped in their blankets beneath the wagon, apparently oblivious to rain or mud, but he would not have wagered on either being asleep. Indeed, one sat up as he squelched up to the wagon. Whichever it was, he said nothing, yet Mat could feel the man's eyes. He did not hesitate, though, and he did not bother with knocking.

ði ɪntɪɹiɝ wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð ɔl sɪks wɪmən ɑn ðɛɹ fit, dʒɹɪpɪŋ kloʊks stɪl ɪn hænd. tu læmps maʊntəɾ ɪn ɡɪmbəlz ɑn ðə wɔlz ɡeɪv ə ɡʊd laɪt, bɛɾɝ ðən i cʊɾə wɪʃt fɔɹ, ɪn ə weɪ. sɪks feɪsəz swɪvəl təwɔɹɾ ɪm wɪð ðoʊz fɹoʊzən lʊks wɪmən ɡeɪv ə mæn wən i pʊɾ ə fʊt wɛɹ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪt. ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə wæɡən smɛld ə dæmp wʊl ən fɛlt əz ɪf laɪtnɪŋ hæd dʒʌst stʃɹʌk, əɹ maɪɾ əɾ ɛni moʊmənt. ɹeɪn dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə ɹuf, ən θʌndɝ ɹoʊld, bʌt ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən fɛl noʊ kulɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ pis ə sɪlvɝ. meɪbi blɹɪk ən fɛn hæd lɛɾ ɪm kʌm ɪnsaɪd θɪŋkɪŋ i wəd ɡɛɾ ɪz hɛd snæpt ɔf. meɪbi ðeɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə steɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs ðɛmsɛlvz. bʌt ðɛn, ə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɹɛɾi tə daɪ ɪf ɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi. nɑt mæt kɔθən. hi pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt wɪð ɪz hɪp. ɪt hɑɹdli ɡeɪv ɪm ə twɪnʒ ɛnimɔɹ. sɛldəm, ɛniweɪ.

The interior was crowded with all six women on their feet, dripping cloaks still in hand. Two lamps mounted in gimbals on the walls gave a good light, better than he could have wished for, in a way. Six faces swiveled toward him with those frozen looks women gave a man when he put a foot where they did not want it. The air in the wagon smelled of damp wool and felt as if lightning had just struck, or might at any moment. Rain drummed on the roof, and thunder rolled, but the foxhead medallion felt no cooler than any other piece of silver. Maybe Blaeric and Fen had let him come inside thinking he would get his head snapped off. Maybe they just wanted to stay out of this themselves. But then, a Warder was ready to die if his Aes Sedai decided it was necessary. Not Mat Cauthon. He pushed the door shut with his hip. It hardly gave him a twinge anymore. Seldom, anyway.

wən i tʃælənʒd ðɛm, idɛzinə fɪɹsli, ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə blæk hɛɹ ðət spɪl daʊn əɹ bæk. "aɪ æm ɡɹeɪtfəl tə jə fəɹ ɹɛskjuɪŋ mi fɹəm ðə sintʃæn, mæstɝ kɔθən, ən əl ʃoʊ maɪ ɡɹæɾətud, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ lɪməts. aɪm nɑt jəɹ sɝvən tə bi ɔɹɾɝd əbaʊt. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sintʃæn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, ən wi kɛpt əɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə sɛn jəɹ . . . wɑtʃdɔɡz . . . æftɝ ʌs." ðə lʊk ʃi ʃɑɾ ət ðə θɹi sintʃæn wɪmən cʊɾə fɹaɪɾ ɛɡz. idɛzinə wɑz oʊvɝ biɪŋ nɝvəs əbaʊɾ ɛniwʌn wɪð ə sintʃæn æksɛnt. ʃi wɑntəd səm ə hɝ oʊn bæk, ən ðə sʌldəm wɝ kloʊs tə hænd.

When he challenged them, Edesina fiercely, shaking out the black hair that spilled down her back. "I am grateful to you for rescuing me from the Seanchan, Master Cauthon, and I will show my gratitude, but there are limits. I am not your servant to be ordered about. There were no Seanchan in the village, and we kept our faces hidden. There was no need to send your . . . watchdogs . . . after us." The look she shot at the three Seanchan women could have fried eggs. Edesina was over being nervous about anyone with a Seanchan accent. She wanted some of her own back, and the sul'dam were close to hand.

mæt wɑz kaʊntɪŋ ɑn ðət feɪbəld ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl tə kip mæɾɝz ʃɔɹɾ ə vaɪələns. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi stʃɹɛtʃt tu fɑɹ tə hoʊld. ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz ɹɪkɔld ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp laɪk ən ɪluməneɪɾɝz wɛɹz.

Mat was counting on that fabled Aes Sedai self-control to keep matters short of violence. He hoped it was not already stretched too far to hold. Those old memories recalled Aes Sedai going up like an Illuminator's wares.

bɛθəmənz dɑɹk feɪs ʃoʊd noʊ saɪn ʌv əlɑɹm. ʃi hæd fɪnɪʃt ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ kloʊk ən hæŋɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn ə pɛɡ waɪl idɛzinə wɑz spikɪŋ, ðən smuðd əɹ dʒɹɛs oʊvɝ əɹ hɪps. tənaɪt, ʃi wɔɹ feɪɾəd ɡɹin pɛɾikoʊts. ʃi kəmpleɪn ðət ði ɛbu dɑɹi ɡɑɹmənt wɑz ɪndisənt, ən i səpoʊz ðəɾ i wəɾ əv tə faɪn əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls naʊ ðeɪ wɝ əweɪ fɹəm ðə koʊst, bʌt ʃi dɪd fɪl aʊt ðət vɛɹi loʊ nɛɹoʊ nɛklaɪn naɪsli. ʃi saʊndəd tu mʌtʃ laɪk ə mʌðɝ fəɹ ɪz teɪst, ðoʊ. "ðeɪ dɪd kip ðɛɹ feɪsəz hɪɾən, maɪ lɔɹd," ʃi dʒɹɔld, "æn ðeɪ steɪd təɡɛðɝ. noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə snik ɔf.

Bethamin's dark face showed no sign of alarm. She had finished shaking out her cloak and hanging it on a peg while Edesina was speaking, then smoothed her dress over her hips. Tonight, she wore faded green petticoats. She complained that the Ebou Dari garment was indecent, and he supposed that he would have to find her something else now they were away from the coast, but she did fill out that very low narrow neckline nicely. She sounded too much like a mother for his taste, though. "They did keep their faces hidden, my Lord," she drawled, "and they stayed together. No one tried to sneak off.

vɛɹi wɛl bɪheɪvd, ɔl ɪn ɔl." ə mʌðɝ pɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. əɹ meɪbi ə dɔɡ tʃɹeɪnɝ pɹeɪzɪŋ ðə dɑɡz.

Very well behaved, all in all." A mother praising her children. Or maybe a dog trainer praising the dogs.

jɛloʊhɛɹd sɛɾə nɑɾəd əpɹuvɪŋli. dɛfənətli ə dɔɡ tʃɹeɪnɝ. "ɪf maɪ lɔɹd wɪʃɪz tə kip əm kənfaɪnd," ɹɛnə sɛd fʊlsəmli, "wi kən ɔlweɪz juz ði eɪwʌn dæm. ðeɪ ɹɪli ʃʊdn bi tʃɹʌstɪd lus." ʃi ivən ɔfɝɾ ɪm ə baʊ, ɪn ðə sintʃæn weɪ, bɛndɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɾ ə ʃɑɹp ɹaɪɾ æŋɡəl. hɝ bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz lʊk hoʊpfəl. tɛslɪn ɡæspt ən klʌtʃt əɹ wɛt kloʊk tə hɝ bʊzəm. ʃi sɝɾənli wɑz nɑɾ oʊvɝ əɹ fɪɹ ə ðə sʌldəm, fəɹ ɔl ʃi lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi kəɾ it neɪlz. dʒoʊlin, hɔɾi əz ɛvɝ, dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, aɪz flæʃɪŋ. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi əɹ noʊ, laɪtnɪŋ maɪɾ əz wɛl stʃɹaɪk wən dʒoʊlinz aɪz stɑɹɾəd flæʃɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɔfən soʊ wɪð pɹɪɾi wɪmən.

Yellowhaired Seta nodded approvingly. Definitely a dog trainer. "If my Lord wishes to keep them confined," Renna said fulsomely, "we can always use the a1 dam. They really shouldn't be trusted loose." She even offered him a bow, in the Seanchan way, bending herself at a sharp right angle. Her big brown eyes looked hopeful. Teslyn gasped and clutched her wet cloak to her bosom. She certainly was not over her fear of the sul'dam, for all she looked as though she could eat nails. Joline, haughty as ever, drew herself up, eyes flashing. Aes Sedai serenity or no, lightning might as well strike when Joline's eyes started flashing. It was often so with pretty women.

"noʊ," mæt sɛd heɪstəli. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt. jə ɡɪv ðoʊz θɪŋz tə mi, ən əl ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm." laɪt, waɪ hæɾ i ɛvɝ sæɾəld hɪmsɛlf wɪð ðiz wɪmən? wʌt sim ðə bɛst aɪdiə ət ðə taɪm kəd lʊk pjʊɹ kwɪl stupəɾ ɪn haɪndsaɪt. "ɔl ə jə dʒʌst əv tə bi kɛɹfəl. wɝ nɑt θɝɾi maɪlz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ jɛt. ðə ɹoʊdz ɑɹ fʊl ə blʌɾi sintʃæn." hi ɡeɪv ən əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk lʊk tə ðə θɹi sintʃæn wɪmən. ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ɪz saɪd, æftɝ ɔl. ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd noʊwɛɹ ɛls tə ɡoʊ ɪksɛpt ɛdʒiənɪn, ən ðeɪ hæd ɹilaɪzd u hæd ðə mʌni. bɛθəmənz aɪbɹaʊz twɪtʃt ʌpwɝɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. sintʃæn noʊbəlz dɪd nɑɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz, ivən wɪð ə ɡlæns.

"No," Mat said hastily. "There's no need for that. You give those things to me, and I'll get rid of them." Light, why had he ever saddled himself with these women? What seemed the best idea at the time could look pure quill stupid in hindsight. "All of you just have to be careful. We're not thirty miles from Ebou Dar yet. The roads are full of bloody Seanchan." He gave an apologetic look to the three Seanchan women. They were on his side, after all. In a manner of speaking. They had nowhere else to go except Egeanin, and they had realized who had the money. Bethamin's eyebrows twitched upward in surprise. Seanchan nobles did not apologize, even with a glance.

"sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz dɪd pæs θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ jɛstɝdeɪ," tɛslɪn sɛd, hɝ ɪliɑnɝ æksɛn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli stʃɹɔŋ. dʒoʊlinz flæʃɪŋ aɪz ʃɪftəd tə hɝ, bʌt ʃi tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs bɪɑn tɝnɪŋ əweɪ tə hæŋ ʌp əɹ oʊn kloʊk. "ðeɪ dɪɾ æsk kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. ən səm dɪd kəmpleɪn əbaʊt biɪŋ sɛnt nɔɹθ." tɛslɪn ɡlænst oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə sʌldəm, ðən dʒɝkt əɹ aɪz əweɪ ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪt dʌz sim ðə ɹɪtɝn bi eɪmd ist. ðə soʊlʒɝz dɪd bɪliv ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi wɪl pɹizɛn ɪljən tə ðɛɹ ɛmpɹɛs bɪfɔɹ ði ɛn ə spɹɪŋ. ðə sɪɾi ɪtsɛlf, ən ɔl ðə ɹɛst." səpoʊzədli ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ʌp ðə lænz ə ðɛɹ bɝθ wən ðeɪ wɛn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt tə ɛni ɪliɑnɝ, ðə sɪɾi ʌv ɪljən wɑz 'ðə sɪɾi,' ən jə kəd hɪɹ ðə kæpəɾəl. "ðæts ɡʊd," mæt sɛd hæf tə hɪmsɛlf, θɪŋkɪŋ. soʊlʒɝz tɔkt aʊɾ ə tɝn ɔl ðə taɪm; ðət wɑz wʌn ɹizən jə dɪd nɑt tɛl jəɹ plænz tə ɛvɹi tʃɹupɝ əntɪl ðə læs mɪnət. tɛslɪnz θɪn aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz, ən i æɾəd, "ɪt minz ðə ɹoʊd tə luɡɹd wɪl bi klɪɹ moʊst ə ðə weɪ." tɛslɪnz nɑd wɑz kɝɾ ən nɑt vɛɹi plizd. wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə də ən wʌt ðeɪ dɪd wɝ ɔfən waɪdli dɪfɹənt.

"Seanchan soldiers did pass through the village yesterday," Teslyn said, her Illianer accent particularly strong. Joline's flashing eyes shifted to her, but she took no notice beyond turning away to hang up her own cloak. "They did ask questions about strangers on the road. And some did complain about being sent north." Teslyn glanced over her shoulder at the sul'dam, then jerked her eyes away and took a deep breath. "It does seem the Return be aimed east. The soldiers did believe the Ever Victorious Army will present Illian to their empress before the end of spring. The City itself, and all the rest." Supposedly Aes Sedai gave up the lands of their birth when they went to the White Tower, but to any Illianer, the city of Illian was 'the City,' and you could hear the capital. "That's good," Mat said half to himself, thinking. Soldiers talked out of turn all the time; that was one reason you did not tell your plans to every trooper until the last minute. Teslyn's thin eyebrows rose, and he added, "It means the road to Lugard will be clear most of the way." Teslyn's nod was curt and not very pleased. What Aes Sedai were supposed to do and what they did were often widely different.

"wi dɪdn spik tə ɛniwʌn, maɪ lɔɹd, oʊnli wɑtʃt ðə ɡɝlz," bɛθəmən sɛd, ivən mɔɹ sloʊli ðən juʒəwəl, ən sintʃæn juʒəwəli tɔk laɪk hʌni pɔɹɪŋ ɪn ə snoʊstɔɹm. ʃi wɑz klɪɹli ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ əmʌŋ ðə θɹi sʌldəm, bʌt ʃi lʊkt əɾ itʃ ə ði ʌðɝz bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ɔl ðə tɔk ɪn ðə sʌldəm kɔɹɾɝz wɑz ʌv ɪljən. ə fæt læn ən ə fæt sɪɾi, wɛɹ mɛni wəɾ ɝn nu neɪmz. ən wɛlθ." ʃi tɔs ðəɾ ɪn əz ɪf wɛlθ hɑɹdli kaʊntəɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ə nu neɪm. "wi ʃʊɾə ɹilaɪz jud wɑnə noʊ əbaʊt sətʃ θɪŋz." ənʌðɝ dip bɹɛθ ɔlmoʊs pɑpt əɹ aʊɾ ə ðət dʒɹɛs. "ɪf juv ɛni kwɛstʃənz, maɪ lɔɹd, wɪl tɛl jə wʌt wi noʊ." ɹɛnə meɪɾ ɪm ənʌðɝ baʊ, hɝ feɪs iɡɝ, ən sɛɾə paɪpt ʌp wɪð, "wi kəd lɪsən ɪn ðə taʊnz ən vɪlədʒəz wɛɹ wi stɑp, tu, maɪ lɔɹd. ðə ɡɝlz kən bi ʃɪfti, bʌt jə kən tʃɹʌst ʌs." waɪ, wən ə wʊmən ɔfɝd tə hɛlp ju, dɪd ʃi ɔlweɪz stɑɹt baɪ stɪkɪŋ jə ɪn ə pɑɾ ə hɑt wɔɾɝ ən stoʊkɪŋ ʌp ðə faɪɝ?

"We didn't speak to anyone, my Lord, only watched the girls," Bethamin said, even more slowly than usual, and Seanchan usually talked like honey pouring in a snowstorm. She was clearly in charge among the three sul'dam, but she looked at each of the others before going on. "In Ebou Dar, all the talk in the sul'dam quarters was of Illian. A fat land and a fat city, where many would earn new names. And wealth." She tossed that in as if wealth hardly counted alongside a new name. "We should have realized you'd want to know about such things." Another deep breath almost popped her out of that dress. "If you have any questions, my Lord, we'll tell you what we know." Renna made him another bow, her face eager, and Seta piped up with, "We could listen in the towns and villages where we stop, too, my Lord. The girls can be shifty, but you can trust us." Why, when a woman offered to help you, did she always start by sticking you in a pot of hot water and stoking up the fire?

dʒoʊlinz feɪs bɪkeɪm ə dɪsdeɪnfəl mæsk ʌv aɪs. ðə sintʃæn wɪmən wɝ bɪniθ əɹ noʊɾəs; ʃi meɪd ðət klɪɹ wɪð ə ɡlæns. ɪt wɑz mæt blʌɾi kɔθən u ɹəsivd əɹ fɹizɪŋ ɡeɪz. idɛzinəz maʊθ θɪnd, ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stɛɹ hoʊlz ɪn ɪm ən ðə sʌldəm boʊθ. ivən tɛslɪn mænədʒd ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. ʃi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ɹɛskju, tu, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ʃi dɝɛktəɾ əɹ fɹaʊn ət hɪm.

Joline's face became a disdainful mask of ice. The Seanchan women were beneath her notice; she made that clear with a glance. It was Mat bloody Cauthon who received her freezing gaze. Edesina's mouth thinned, and she tried to stare holes in him and the sul'dam both. Even Teslyn managed indignation. She was grateful for rescue, too, but she was Aes Sedai. And she directed her frown at him.

hi səspɛktəd ʃi wəd dʒʌmp laɪk ə stɑɹɾəld fɹɑɡ ɪf wʌn ə ðə sʌl'-dæm klæpt əɹ hænz.

He suspected she would jump like a startled frog if one of the sul'-dam clapped her hands.

"wʌɾ aɪ wɑnt," hi ɪkspleɪn peɪʃənli, "ɪz fəɹ ɔl ə jə tə steɪ wɪð ðə wæɡənz." jə hæd tə bi peɪʃənt wɪð wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi wɑz blʌɾi wɛl lɝnɪŋ ðət baɪ hɑɹt. "wʌn wɪspɝ ðɛɹz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð ðɪs ʃoʊ, ən wɪl bi hɪp-dip ɪn sintʃæn hʌntɪŋ fəɹ hɝ. ɹumɝz ə sintʃæn wɪð ðə ʃoʊ woʊn sɝv əs ɛni bɛɾɝ. iðɝ weɪ, sʌmbɑɾi wɪl kʌm tə faɪn aʊt wʌts bɪhaɪn ɪt sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən wɪl ɔl bi ɪn ðə pɪklɪŋ kɛɾəl. doʊn flɔn jʊɹsɛlvz. jə nid tə steɪ loʊ tɪl wi ɡɛt kloʊsɝ tə luɡɹd. ðəɾ ɪzən soʊ mʌtʃ tə æsk, naʊ ɪz ɪt?" laɪtnɪŋ lɪɾ ʌp ðə wæɡənz wɪndoʊz wɪð ə blu flæʃ, ən θʌndɝ kɹæʃt oʊvɝhɛd, soʊ kloʊs ɪt ɹæɾəld ðə wæɡən.

"What I want," he explained patiently, "is for all of you to stay with the wagons." You had to be patient with women, including Aes Sedai. He was bloody well learning that by heart. "One whisper there's an Aes Sedai with this show, and we'll be hip-deep in Seanchan hunting for her. Rumors of Seanchan with the show won't serve us any better. Either way, somebody will come to find out what's behind it sooner or later, and we'll all be in the pickling kettle. Don't flaunt yourselves. You need to stay low till we get closer to Lugard. That isn't so much to ask, now is it?" Lightning lit up the wagon's windows with a blue flash, and thunder crashed overhead, so close it rattled the wagon.

ɪt wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə æsk, əpɛɹənli, əz ðə deɪz wɔɹ ɑn. oʊ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kɛp ðɛɹ hʊdz wɛl ʌp wən ðeɪ wɛn aʊtsaɪd - ðə ɹeɪn ɡeɪv ɪnʌf ɪkskjus fəɹ ðæt; ðə ɹeɪn ən ðə koʊld - bʌt wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ɹoʊɾ ɑn ðə wæɡən siɾ əz ɔfən əz nɑt, ən ðeɪ meɪd noʊ ɹil ɛfɝt tə pæs əz sɝvəns ɝaʊn ðə ʃoʊfoʊk. nɑt ðət ðeɪ ədmɪɾəd u ðeɪ wɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, əɹ ɔɹɾɝd ɛniwʌn əbaʊɾ əɹ ivən spoʊk tə ɛniwʌn mʌtʃ bɪsaɪdz itʃ ʌðɝ, bʌt wʌt sɝvən klɪɹli ɪkspɛktəd pipəl tə muv aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ?

It was too much to ask, apparently, as the days wore on. Oh, the Aes Sedai kept their hoods well up when they went outside - the rain gave enough excuse for that; the rain and the cold - but one or another rode on the wagon seat as often as not, and they made no real effort to pass as servants around the showfolk. Not that they admitted who they were, of course, or ordered anyone about or even spoke to anyone much besides each other, but what servant clearly expected people to move out of her way?

ðeɪ wɛn ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒəz, tu, ən səmtaɪmz ðə taʊnz, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sintʃæn ðɛɹ. wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ ə sʌmθɪŋ, ɪt hæd tə bi tʃɹu. twaɪs ðeɪ keɪm skɝiɪŋ bæk wən ðeɪ faʊn ə taʊn hæf-fʊl ə sɛtlɝz ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ nɔɹθ. ðeɪ toʊld ɪm wʌt ðeɪ lɝn ɑn ðɛɹ vɪzəts. hi θɔt ðeɪ dɪd. tɛslɪn dɪd sim ɡɹeɪtfəl, æftɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fæʃən. ən idɛzinə. æftɝ ə fæʃən.

They went into the villages, too, and sometimes the towns, if they were sure there were no Seanchan there. When an Aes Sedai was sure of something, it had to be true. Twice they came scurrying back when they found a town half-full of settlers on their way north. They told him what they learned on their visits. He thought they did. Teslyn did seem grateful, after an Aes Sedai fashion. And Edesina. After a fashion.

dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ dɪfɝənsɪz, dʒoʊlin, tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə stʌk təɡɛðɝ laɪk hɝɾɪd ɡis. ɪf jə sɔ wʌn, jə sɔ ɔl θɹi. laɪkli ðət wɑz kəz wən jə sɔ ðɛm teɪkɪŋ ə stʃɹoʊl, ɔl nitli kloʊkt ən hɪɾən əz ðeɪ wɝ, ə mɪnət leɪɾɝ bɛθəmən ən ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə əpɪɹd tʃɹeɪlɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm. oʊ soʊ kæʒəwəli, bʌt nɛvɝ lɛɾɪŋ "ðə ɡɝlz" aʊɾ ə saɪt. ðə ɡus-hɝdz. ə blaɪn mæn kəd si ðəɹ wɑz tɛnʃən bɪtwin ðə tu ɡɹups ʌv wɪmən. ə blaɪn mæn kəd si nʌn ə ðɛm wɝ sɝvəns. ðə sʌldəm hæd hɛld ɹɪspɛktɪd pəzɪʃənz, pəzɪʃənz ʌv əθɔɹəɾi, ən ðeɪ muvd ɔlmoʊst əz ɛɹəɡənli əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi wɑz stʌk wɪð ðə stɔɹi, ðoʊ.

Despite their differences, Joline, Teslyn and Edesina stuck together like herded geese. If you saw one, you saw all three. Likely that was because when you saw them taking a stroll, all neatly cloaked and hidden as they were, a minute later Bethamin and Renna and Seta appeared trailing after them. Oh so casually, but never letting "the girls" out of sight. The goose-herds. A blind man could see there was tension between the two groups of women. A blind man could see none of them were servants. The sul'dam had held respected positions, positions of authority, and they moved almost as arrogantly as the Aes Sedai. He was stuck with the story, though.

bɛθəmən ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ əz lɪɹi ʌv ʌðɝ sintʃæn əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ, jɛt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ fɑloʊd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wən ðeɪ wɛn ɪndə ə vɪlədʒ əɹ taʊn, ən bɛθəmən ɔlweɪz ɹipɔɹɾəd ðə tɪdbɪts ðeɪ hæd pɪkt ʌp baɪ ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, wɪð ɹɛnə wɛɹɪŋ ən ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ smaɪl ən sɛɾə tʃɝpɪŋ ɪn ðət 'ðə ɡɝlz' hæd mɪs ðɪs əɹ ðæt, əɹ kleɪm nɑt tə hæv hɝd; jə kəd nɛvɝ bi ʃʊɹ wɪð sʌmwʌn u hæd ði ɑdæsəɾi tə kɔl hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ; meɪbi hi ʃəd ɹikənsɪɾɝ hævɪŋ əm liʃt, dʒʌs tɪl ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz seɪf.

Bethamin and the other two were as leery of other Seanchan as the Aes Sedai were, yet they also followed the Aes Sedai when they went into a village or town, and Bethamin always reported the tidbits they had picked up by eavesdropping, with Renna wearing an ingratiating smile and Seta chirping in that 'the girls' had missed this or that, or claimed not to have heard; you could never be sure with someone who had the audacity to call herself Aes Sedai; maybe he should reconsider having them leashed, just till everything was safe.
