ðɛɹ teɪlz ɹɪli wɝ nɑt ðət dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌt ðə sɪstɝz toʊl hɪm. taʊnzfoʊks tɔk ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd fɹəm sintʃæn pæsɪŋ θɹu. mɛni ʌv ðə sɛtlɝz wɝ nɝvəs, ðɛɹ hɛdz fʊl ə teɪlz əbaʊt sævədʒ il ɹævɪdʒɪŋ θɹu ɔltɑɹə, ðoʊ ðə loʊkəl pipəl ɔl sɛd ðət wɑz ʌp nɔɹθ sʌmwɛɹ. ɪt sim sʌmwʌn haɪɝ maɪt bi θɪŋkɪŋ ðə seɪm, ðoʊ, kəz mɛni sɛtlɝz hæd bɪn daɪvɝɾɪd ist, təwɔɹɾ ɪljən. ən əlaɪəns hæd bɪn kənkluɾəd wɪð sʌmwʌn paʊɝfəl u wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə ɡɪv ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ æksɛs tə mɛni lænz. ðə wɪmən ɹəfjuz tə bi kənvɪns ðət ðeɪ nid nɑt lɪsən fəɹ ɹumɝz. ðeɪ nɛvɝ kwaɪt ɡɑɾ ɝaʊn tə hændɪŋ oʊvɝ ði æɾəm, iðɝ. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðoʊz sɪlvɝi liʃɪz ən ðə θɹi sʌldəm wɝ ði oʊnli ɹil lɛvɝ i hæd wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡɹæɾətud.

Their tales really were not that different from what the sisters told him. Townsfolk's talk of what they had overheard from Seanchan passing through. Many of the settlers were nervous, their heads full of tales about savage Aiel ravaging through Altara, though the local people all said that was up north somewhere. It seemed someone higher might be thinking the same, though, because many settlers had been diverted east, toward Illian. An alliance had been concluded with someone powerful who was expected to give the High Lady Suroth access to many lands. The women refused to be convinced that they need not listen for rumors. They never quite got around to handing over the a'dam, either. In truth, those silvery leashes and the three sul'dam were the only real lever he had with the Aes Sedai. Gratitude.

fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ! hɑ! nɑt ðəɾ i ɹɪli θɔɾ əbaʊt pʊɾɪŋ ðoʊz kɑlɝz ɑn ðə sɪstɝz əɡɛn. nɑɾ ɔfən, ɛniweɪ. hi wɑz wɛl ən tʃɹuli stʌk.

From an Aes Sedai! Ha! Not that he really thought about putting those collars on the sisters again. Not often, anyway. He was well and truly stuck.

hi tʃɹuli dɪɾ əv noʊ niɾ ʌv wʌt ðə sʌldəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ lɝnd. hi hæd bɛɾɝ sɔɹsəz, pipəl i tʃɹʌstɪd. wɛl, hi tʃɹʌstɪd tɑm, wən ðə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡlimən kəd bi ɹuɾəd aʊt fɹəm pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪð oʊlvɝ əɹ munɪŋ oʊvɝ ə mʌkkɹis lɛɾɝ i kæɹid tʌkt ɪn ðə bɹɛst ə hɪz koʊt. tɑm kəd wɔk ɪndə ə kɑmən ɹum, tɛl ə stɔɹi, meɪbi dʒʌɡəl ə bɪt, ən wɔk aʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɪn ðə hɛɾ ʌv ɛvɹi mæn ðɛɹ.

He truly did have no need of what the sul'dam and Aes Sedai learned. He had better sources, people he trusted. Well, he trusted Thom, when the white-haired gleeman could be routed out from playing Snakes and Foxes with Olver or mooning over a muchcreased letter he carried tucked in the breast of his coat. Thom could walk into a common room, tell a story, maybe juggle a bit, and walk out knowing what was in the head of every man there.

mæt tʃɹʌstɪd dʒulɪn, tu - hi dɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz tɑm, wɪθaʊt dʒʌɡəlɪŋ əɹ stɔɹitɛlɪŋ - bʌt dʒulɪn ɔlweɪz ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn teɪkɪŋ θɛɹə wɪð hɪm, dɪmjʊɹli klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz ɑɹm əz ðeɪ stʃɹoʊld ɪndə ə taʊn.

Mat trusted Juilin, too - he did almost as well as Thom, without juggling or storytelling - but Juilin always insisted on taking Thera with him, demurely clutching his arm as they strolled into a town.

tə ɡɛɾ əɹ juz tə fɹiɾəm əɡɛn, ðə mæn sɛd. ʃi smaɪld ʌp ət dʒulɪn, ðoʊz bɪɡ aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ dɑɹkli, ðət fʊl lɪɾəl maʊθ æskɪŋ tə bi kɪst. meɪbi ʃi hæd bɪn pɑnɑɹtʃ ə tæɹɑbən, ðə weɪ dʒulɪn ən tɑm kleɪmd, bʌt mæt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə daʊɾ ɪt. hi hæd hɝd səm ə ðə kəntɔɹʃənɪsts dʒoʊkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ ðə tæɹɑbənɝ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ðə tɛɹən θif-kætʃɝ aʊt tɪl i kəd bɛɹli wɔk.

To get her used to freedom again, the man said. She smiled up at Juilin, those big eyes shining darkly, that full little mouth asking to be kissed. Maybe she had been Panarch of Tarabon, the way Juilin and Thom claimed, but Mat was beginning to doubt it. He had heard some of the contortionists joking about how the Taraboner serving girl was wearing the Tairen thief-catcher out till he could barely walk.

pɑnɑɹtʃ əɹ sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl, ðoʊ, θɛɹə stɪl stɑɹɾəd tə nil ɛni taɪm ʃi hɝɾ ə dʒɹɔlɪŋ æksɛnt. mæt fɪɡjɝd ðəɾ ɛni sintʃæn u æskt əɹ ə kwɛstʃən wəd ɡɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð dʒulɪn sændɑɹ ən ɛndɪŋ wɪð wɪtʃ wæɡən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɪn, ɔl ænsɝz dɪlɪvɝd fɹəm əɹ niz.

Panarch or serving girl, though, Thera still started to kneel any time she heard a drawling accent. Mat figured that any Seanchan who asked her a question would get everything she knew, beginning with Juilin Sandar and ending with which wagon the Aes Sedai were in, all answers delivered from her knees.

θɛɹə wɑz ə bɪɡɝ deɪnʒɝ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən sʌldəm pʊt təɡɛðɝ, ɪn ɪz bʊk. dʒulɪn bɹaɪɾəld ət ðə slaɪɾəst sədʒɛstʃən ɪz wʊmən maɪt bi ʌnɹɪlaɪəbəl, ðoʊ, ən spʌn ɪz bæmbu stæf əz ɪf i wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ kɹækɪŋ mæts hɛd fəɹ hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ səluʃən, bʌt mæt faʊn ə stɑpɡæp, ə weɪ tə ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl wɔɹnɪŋ ɪf ðə wɝst əkɝd.

Thera was a bigger danger than Aes Sedai and sul'dam put together, in his book. Juilin bridled at the slightest suggestion his woman might be unreliable, though, and spun his bamboo staff as if he was considering cracking Mat's head for him. There was no solution, but Mat found a stopgap, a way to get a little warning if the worst occurred.

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ kən fɑloʊ ðɛm," noʊl sɛd, wɪð ə ɡæp-tuθt ɡɹɪn ðət sɛɾ ɪt wəd bi tʃaɪlz pleɪ. leɪɪŋ ə nɑɹl fɪŋɡɝ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪz bɛnt noʊz, hi slɪp ði ʌðɝ nɑbəli hæn bɪniθ ɪz koʊt, wɛɹ i kɛpt ɪz naɪvz. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ɪt wʊdn bi bɛɾɝ dʒʌs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi kæn tɔk tə ɛniwʌn? dʒʌst ə sədʒɛstʃən, læd. ɪf jə seɪ nɑt, ðən nɑt." mæt moʊst ɛmfæɾɪkli sɛd nɑt. hi hæd kɪld wʌn wʊmən ɪn ɪz laɪf, ən lɛft ənʌðɝ tə bi bʊtʃɝd. hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə æɾ ə θɝd tə hɪz soʊl. "ɪt simz sjuɹɔθ maɪɾ əv meɪɾ ən əlaɪəns wɪð səm kɪŋ," dʒulɪn ɹipɔɹɾəd wɪð ə smaɪl oʊvɝ ə kʌp ə mʌld waɪn. ət lis θɛɹə sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ɪm smaɪl mɔɹ. ʃi hʌɾəld bɪsaɪd dʒulɪnz stul ɪn ðɛɹ kɹæmp tɛnt, hɝ hɛd laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz læp, ən i stʃɹoʊkt əɹ hɛɹ sɔfli wɪð ɪz fɹi hænd. "æt list, ðɛɹz kənsɪɾɝəbəl tɔk ə səm paʊɝfəl nu ælaɪ. ən ðoʊz sɛtlɝz ɑɹ ɔl fɹaɪɾənd aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ wɪts baɪ il."

"Of course I can follow them," Noal said, with a gap-toothed grin that said it would be child's play. Laying a gnarled finger alongside his bent nose, he slipped the other knobbly hand beneath his coat, where he kept his knives. "Are you sure it wouldn't be better just to make sure she can't talk to anyone? Just a suggestion, lad. If you say not, then not." Mat most emphatically said not. He had killed one woman in his life, and left another to be butchered. He was not going to add a third to his soul. "It seems Suroth might have made an alliance with some king," Juilin reported with a smile over a cup of mulled wine. At least Thera seemed to be making him smile more. She huddled beside Juilin's stool in their cramped tent, her head lying on his lap, and he stroked her hair softly with his free hand. "At least, there's considerable talk of some powerful new ally. And those settlers are all frightened out of their wits by Aiel."

"moʊst ə ðə sɛtlɝz sim tə bi hæv bɪn sɛn ist," tɑm sɛd, piɹɪŋ sædli ɪndə hɪz kʌp. əz dʒulɪn ɡɹu hæpiɝ deɪ baɪ deɪ, hi sim tə ɡɹoʊ sæɾɝ. noʊl wɑz aʊt ʃæɾoʊɪŋ dʒulɪn ən θɛɹə, ən ləpɪn ən nɹɪm wɝ sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ət ðə bæk ə ðə tɛnt, bʌt ðə tu kɛɹhinɪn sɝvɪŋ mɛn hæd ðɛɹ mɛndɪŋ bæskəts aʊɾ ən wɝ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ mæts ɡʊd koʊts fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ fəɹ ɛni ɹɪpɛɹz ðeɪ θɔt nɛsəsɛɹi, soʊ ðə smɔl tɛn stɪl sim kɹaʊɾəd. "æn ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni soʊlʒɝz, tu," tɑm wɛn ɑn. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ sɛz ðəɹ gɑnə fɔl ɑn ɪljən laɪk ə hæmɝ." wɛl, ət list i nu hi wɑz hɪɹɪŋ ði ənvɑɹnɪʃt tʃɹuθ wən i hɝɾ ɪt fɹəm ðɛm. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ spɪnɪŋ wɝdz ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz əɹ sʌldəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə smɑɹm ðɛɹ weɪ ɪndə hɪz ɡʊd ɡɹeɪsɪz. bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə hæɾ ivən lɝn tə kɝtsi. sʌmhaʊ, hi fɛl mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ɹɛnə bɛndɪŋ hɝsɛlf dʌbəl. ɪt simd ɑnəst.

"Most of the settlers seem to be have been sent east," Thom said, peering sadly into his cup. As Juilin grew happier day by day, he seemed to grow sadder. Noal was out shadowing Juilin and Thera, and Lopin and Nerim were sitting cross-legged at the back of the tent, but the two Cairhienin serving men had their mending baskets out and were examining Mat's good coats from Ebou Dar for any repairs they thought necessary, so the small tent still seemed crowded. "And a great many soldiers, too," Thom went on. "Everything says they're going to fall on Illian like a hammer." Well, at least he knew he was hearing the unvarnished truth when he heard it from them. No Aes Sedai spinning words on their heads or sul'dam trying to smarm their way into his good graces. Bethamin and Seta had even learned to curtsy. Somehow, he felt more comfortable with Renna bending herself double. It seemed honest.

stʃɹeɪnʒ, bʌɾ ɑnəst.

Strange, but honest.

fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ, mæt tʊk noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə kwɪk lʊk ɝaʊnd, wɪð ɪz kɑlɝ tɝn ʌp ən ɪz kæp pʊl daʊn, bɪfɔɹ hɛɾɪŋ bæk tə ðə ʃoʊ. hi sɛldəm wɔɹ ə kloʊk. ə kloʊk kəd meɪk ɪt dɪfəkəl tə juz ðə naɪvz i kæɹid tʌkt əbaʊɾ ɪz pɝsən. nɑt ðəɾ i ɪkspɛktəd tə nid ðɛm.

For himself, town or village, Mat took no more than a quick look around, with his collar turned up and his cap pulled down, before heading back to the show. He seldom wore a cloak. A cloak could make it difficult to use the knives he carried tucked about his person. Not that he expected to need them.

ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə pɹuɾənt pɹikɔʃən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, noʊ dænsɪŋ, ən noʊ ɡæmbəlɪŋ. ɪspɛʃli noʊ ɡæmbəlɪŋ. ðə saʊn ə daɪs ɹætlɪŋ ɑn ə teɪbəl ɪn ən ɪnz kɑmən ɹum pʊld ət hɪm, bʌɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ə lʌk wɪð daɪs wɑz baʊn tə bi ɹɪmɑɹkt, ivən ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt lɛd tə sʌmbɑɾi pʊlɪŋ ə naɪf, ən ɪn ðɪs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɔltɑɹə boʊθ mɛn ən wɪmən kæɹid naɪvz tʌk bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ bɛls ən wɝ ɹɛɾi tə juz ðɛm.

It was just a prudent precaution. There was no drinking, no dancing, and no gambling. Especially no gambling. The sound of dice rattling on a table in an inn's common room pulled at him, but his sort of luck with dice was bound to be remarked, even if it did not lead to somebody pulling a knife, and in this part of Altara both men and women carried knives tucked behind their belts and were ready to use them.

hi wɑntəd tə pæs θɹu ənnoʊɾɪst, soʊ hi wɔk baɪ ðə daɪs ɡeɪmz, nɑɾəd kuli tə ðə tævɝn meɪdz u smaɪld ət hɪm, ən nɛvɝ dʒɹæŋk mɔɹ ðən ə kʌp ʌv waɪn ən juʒəwəli nɑt ðæt. æftɝ ɔl, hi hæd wɝk tə də bæk ət ðə ʃoʊ. wɝk ʌv ə sɔɹt. hi hæd bɪɡʌn ɪt ðə vɛɹi fɝs naɪɾ æftɝ livɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ə ɹʌf dʒɑb ɪt wɑz.

He wanted to pass through unnoticed, so he walked by the dice games, nodded coolly to the tavern maids who smiled at him, and never drank more than a cup of wine and usually not that. After all, he had work to do back at the show. Work of a sort. He had begun it the very first night after leaving Ebou Dar, and a rough job it was.

"aɪ nid jə tə ɡoʊ wɪð mi," hi hæd sɛd ðɛn, pʊlɪŋ oʊpən ðə kʌbɝd bɪlt ɪndə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən bɪniθ ɪz bɛd. hi kɛpt ɪz tʃɛst ʌv ɡoʊld ɪn ðɛɹ, ɔl ɑnəsli kʌm baɪ θɹu ɡæmbəlɪŋ. əz ɑnəsli əz i kʊd, ɛniweɪ. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹt keɪm fɹəm wʌn hɔɹs ɹeɪs, ən ɪz lʌk wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ mænz wɪð hɔɹsəz. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst. . . . ɪf ə mæn wɑntəd tə tɔs daɪs əɹ pleɪ ət kɑɹdz əɹ pɪtʃ kɔɪnz, hi hæd tə bi ɹɛɾi tə luz. doʊmən, siɾəd ɑn ði ʌðɝ bɛd ɹʌbɪŋ ə hæn oʊvɝ ðə bɹɪsəl ɑn ɪz ʃeɪv skælp, hæd lɝn ðət lɛsən. ðə fɛloʊ ʃʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə slip ɑn ðə flɔɹ laɪk ə ɡʊd sɔɪbən, bʌɾ ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ i hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn flɪpɪŋ ə kɔɪn wɪð mæt itʃ naɪt fəɹ ðə sɛkən bɛd. ɛdʒiənɪn ɡɑt ðə fɝst, ʌv kɔɹs. tɔsɪŋ kɔɪnz wɑz əz izi əz dɪk$.

"I need you to go with me," he had said then, pulling open the cupboard built into the side of the wagon beneath his bed. He kept his chest of gold in there, all honestly come by through gambling. As honestly as he could, anyway. The greater part came from one horse race, and his luck was no better than any other man's with horses. For the rest. . . . If a man wanted to toss dice or play at cards or pitch coins, he had to be ready to lose. Domon, seated on the other bed rubbing a hand over the bristle on his shaved scalp, had learned that lesson. The fellow should have been willing to sleep on the floor like a good so'jbin, but in the beginning he had insisted on flipping a coin with Mat each night for the second bed. Egeanin got the first, of course. Tossing coins was as easy as dic$.

əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɔɪn dɪd nɑt læn ɑn ɛdʒ, ðə weɪ ɪt səmtaɪmz dɪd fəɹ hɪm. bʌt doʊmən hæd meɪd ði ɔfɝ, nɑt hɪm. əntɪl mæt hæd wʌn fɔɹ taɪmz stʃɹeɪt, ən ðən ðə fɪfθ naɪt ðə kɔɪn dɪd læn ɑn ɛdʒ, θɹi taɪmz ɪn ə ɹoʊ. ðeɪ tʊk tɝn ən tɝn əbaʊt, naʊ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl dimənz tɝn fəɹ ðə flɔɹ, tənaɪt. faɪndɪŋ ðə smɔlɪʃ wɑʃlðɝ bæɡ hi wɑz æftɝ, hi stʌft ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən stʃɹeɪɾənd, pʊʃɪŋ ðə kʌbɝd ʃʌt wɪð ɪz fʊt. "ju hæv tə feɪs əɹ səm taɪm," hi sɛd. "æn aɪ nid jə tə smuð θɪŋz oʊvɝ." hi niɾəd sʌmwʌn tə ətʃɹæk tuɑnz aɪɹ, sʌmwʌn tə meɪk ɪm sim æksɛptəbəl baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt seɪ ðæt, kəd hi? "jɔɹ ə sintʃæn noʊbəl, ən jə kən kip mi fɹəm pʊɾɪŋ maɪ buɾ ɪn maɪ maʊθ." "waɪ dʒju nid tə smuð θɪŋz oʊvɝ?" ɛdʒiənɪnz dʒɹɔl wɑz hɑɹɾ əz ə sɔ. ʃi stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə wæɡənz dɔɹ wɪð əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, blu aɪz ɔdʒɝɪŋ aʊt fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ lɔŋ blæk wɪɡ. "waɪ dʒju nid tə si hɝ? hævən jə dʌn ɪnʌf?" "doʊn tɛl mi jəɹ əfɹeɪɾ ə hɝ," mæt skɔft, dɑdʒɪŋ ðə kwɛstʃən. wʌɾ ænsɝ kəɾ i ɡɪv ðət dɪd nɑt saʊn ɪnseɪn? "ju kəd tʌk əɹ ʌndɝ jəɹ ɑɹm ɔlmoʊst əz izəli əz aɪ kʊd. bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs nɑt tə lɛɾ əɹ kʌt jəɹ hɛɾ ɔf əɹ bit jə ʌp." "ɛdʒiənɪn də noʊ bi əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, bɔɪ," doʊmən ɡɹaʊl pɹoʊtɛktɪvli. "ɪf ʃi dʌz noʊ wɑnə ɡoʊ, ðən jə tʃɹɑɾ ɔf tə kɔɹt ðə ɡɝl baɪ jɝsɛlf.

As long as the coin did not land on edge, the way it sometimes did for him. But Domon had made the offer, not him. Until Mat had won four times straight, and then the fifth night the coin did land on edge, three times in a row. They took turn and turn about, now. But it was still Demon's turn for the floor, tonight. Finding the smallish washleather bag he was after, he stuffed it into his coat pocket and straightened, pushing the cupboard shut with his foot. "You have to face her some time," he said. "And I need you to smooth things over." He needed someone to attract Tuon's ire, someone to make him seem acceptable by comparison, but he could not say that, could he? "You're a Seanchan noble, and you can keep me from putting my boot in my mouth." "Why do you need to smooth things over?" Egeanin's drawl was hard as a saw. She stood against the wagon's door with her fists on her hips, blue eyes augering out from beneath her long black wig. "Why do you need to see her? Haven't you done enough?" "Don't tell me you're afraid of her," Mat scoffed, dodging the question. What answer could he give that did not sound insane? "You could tuck her under your arm almost as easily as I could. But I promise not to let her cut your head off or beat you up." "Egeanin do no be afraid of anything, boy," Domon growled protectively. "If she does no want to go, then you trot off to court the girl by yourself.

steɪ ðə naɪt, ɪf jə tʃuz." ɛdʒiənɪn kəntɪnjud tə ɡlɛɹ ət mæt. əɹ θɹu hɪm. ðən ʃi ɡlænst ət doʊmən, hɝ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt ə lɪɾəl, ən ʃi snætʃt əɹ kloʊk fɹəm ɪts pɛɡ ɑn ðə wɔl. "ɡɛɾ ə muv ɑn, kɔθən," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. "ɪf ɪts tə bi dʌn, bɛst ɪts dʌn ən oʊvɝ wɪð." ʃi wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡən ɪn ə flæʃ, ən mæt hæd tə hɝi tə kætʃ əɹ ʌp. jə kəɾ ɔlmoʊs θɪŋk ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi əloʊn wɪð doʊmən, əz lɪɾəl sɛns əz ðət meɪd.

Stay the night, if you choose." Egeanin continued to glare at Mat. Or through him. Then she glanced at Domon, her shoulders slumped a little, and she snatched her cloak from its peg on the wall. "Get a move on, Cauthon," she growled. "If it has to be done, best it's done and over with." She was out of the wagon in a flash, and Mat had to hurry to catch her up. You could almost think she did not want to be alone with Domon, as little sense as that made.

aʊtsaɪd ðə wɪndoʊləs pɝpəl wæɡən, blæk ɪn ðə naɪt, ə ʃædoʊ ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz. ðə sɪkəl mun keɪm aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə klaʊdz lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ mæt tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɑɹnənz læntɝn dʒɔ.

Outside the windowless purple wagon, black in the night, a shadow shifted in the deeper shadows. The sickle moon came out from behind the clouds long enough for Mat to recognize Harnan's lantern jaw.

"ɔl kwaɪət, maɪ lɔɹd," ðə faɪl-liɾɝ sɛd. mæt nɑɾəd ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, filɪŋ fəɹ ðə wɑʃlðɝ bæɡ ɪn ɪz pɑkət. ði ɛɹ wɑz klin, wɑʃt baɪ ðə ɹeɪn ən əweɪ fɹəm ðə hɔɹslaɪnz.

"All quiet, my Lord," the file-leader said. Mat nodded and took a deep breath, feeling for the washleather bag in his pocket. The air was clean, washed by the rain and away from the horselines.

tuɑn mʌs bi ɹɪliv tə bi əweɪ fɹəm ðə dʌŋ smɛl, ən ðə ɹæŋk oʊɾɝ ə ði ænəməl keɪdʒɪz. ðə pɝfɔɹmɝz' wæɡənz tə hɪz lɛft wɝ əz dɑɹk əz ðə kænvəs-tɑp stɔɹədʒ wæɡənz tə hɪz ɹaɪt. noʊ jus weɪɾɪŋ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. hi pʊʃt ɛdʒiənɪn ʌp ðə pɝpəl wæɡənz stɛps əhɛɾ ə hɪm.

Tuon must be relieved to be away from the dung smell, and the rank odor of the animal cages. The performers' wagons to his left were as dark as the canvas-topped storage wagons to his right. No use waiting any longer. He pushed Egeanin up the purple wagon's steps ahead of him.

ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ pipəl ɪnsaɪd ðən i ɪkspɛktəd. sɛɾəl wɑz siɾəd ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɛdz, wɝkɪŋ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup əɡɛn, ən sɪlutʃə stʊɾ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn skaʊlɪŋ bɪniθ əɹ hɛd skɑɹf, bʌt noʊl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ bɛd, əpɛɹənli lɔst ɪn θɔt, ən tuɑn sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ pleɪɪŋ sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪð oʊlvɝ.

There were more people inside than he expected. Setalle was seated on one of the beds, working her embroidery hoop again, and Selucia stood at the far end scowling beneath her head scarf, but Noal was sitting on the other bed, apparently lost in thought, and Tuon sat cross-legged on the floor playing Snakes and Foxes with Olver.

ðə bɔɪ twɪstəɾ ɝaʊnd wɪð ə waɪd-maʊðd ɡɹɪn ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst splɪɾ ɪz feɪs wən mæt keɪm ɪn.

The boy twisted around with a wide-mouthed grin that almost split his face when Mat came in.

"noʊl əz bɪn tɛlɪŋ əs əbaʊt koʊɾənsɪn, mæt," hi ɪkskleɪmd. "ðæts ənʌðɝ neɪm fəɹ ʃɑɹə. dɪd jə noʊ ði aɪɑd tætu ðɛɹ feɪsəz? ðæts wʌt ðeɪ kɔl wɪmən u kən tʃænəl, ɪn ʃɑɹə."

"Noal has been telling us about Co'dansin, Mat," he exclaimed. "That's another name for Shara. Did you know the Ayyad tattoo their faces? That's what they call women who can channel, in Shara."

"noʊ, aɪ dɪdnt," mæt sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ ə ɡɹɪm aɪ ɑn noʊl. ɪt wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf ðət veɪnɪn ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wɝ titʃɪŋ ðə bɔɪ bæd hæbəts, nɑt tə mɛnʃən wʌɾ i wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp fɹəm dʒulɪn ən tɑm, wɪθaʊt noʊl fɪlɪŋ ɪz hɛd wɪð meɪd-ʌp nɑnsɛns. sʌɾənli noʊl slæpt ɪz θaɪ ən sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ naʊ," hi sɛd, ən ðən ðə ful bɪɡæn tə ɹəsaɪt.

"No, I didn't," Mat said, settling a grim eye on Noal. It was bad enough that Vanin and the Redarms were teaching the boy bad habits, not to mention what he was picking up from Juilin and Thom, without Noal filling his head with made-up nonsense. Suddenly Noal slapped his thigh and sat up straight. "I remember now," he said, and then the fool began to recite.

"fɔɹtʃən ɹaɪdz laɪk ðə sʌn ɑn haɪ wɪð ðə fɑks ðət meɪks ðə ɹeɪvənz flaɪ.

"Fortune rides like the sun on high with the fox that makes the ravens fly.

lʌk ɪz soʊl, ðə laɪtnɪŋ ɪz aɪ, hi snætʃɪz ðə munz fɹəm aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ."

Luck his soul, the lightning his eye, He snatches the moons from out of the sky."

ðə bɹoʊkən-noʊzd oʊl mæn lʊkt ɝaʊn əz ɪf dʒʌst ɹilaɪzɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz ðɛɹ. "aɪv bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. ɪts fɹəm ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən."

The broken-nosed old man looked around as if just realizing anyone else was there. "I've been trying to remember that. It's from the Prophecies of the Dragon."

"vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, noʊl," mæt mʌɾɝd. ðoʊz kʌlɝz wɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd dʒʌs ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ pænɪkɪŋ. ðeɪ flæʃt əweɪ wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ ə pɪktʃɝ ðɪs taɪm, bʌɾ i fɛlt əz koʊld əz ɪf i hæd spɛn ə naɪt slipɪŋ ʌndɝ ə bʊʃ ɪn ɪz skɪn. ðə læs θɪŋ ɑn ɝθ i niɾəd wɑz ɛnibəɾi ɛls lɪŋkɪŋ ɪm tə ðə pɹɑfəsiz. "meɪbi səm taɪm jə kən ɹəsaɪt ðə hoʊl θɪŋ fəɹ ʌs. bʌt nɑt tənaɪt, ɛ?"

"Very interesting, Noal," Mat muttered. Those colors whirled in his head just the way they had that morning, when the Aes Sedai were panicking. They flashed away without making a picture this time, but he felt as cold as if he had spent a night sleeping under a bush in his skin. The last thing on earth he needed was anybody else linking him to the Prophecies. "Maybe some time you can recite the whole thing for us. But not tonight, eh?"

tuɑn lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm θɹu hɝ aɪlæʃɪz, ə blæk pɔɹsələn dɑl ɪn ə dʒɹɛs ðət wɑz tu bɪɡ fəɹ hɝ. laɪt, bʌt ʃi hæd lɔŋ læʃɪz. ʃi ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɛdʒiənɪn əz ɪf ði ʌðɝ wʊmən dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst, ən ɪn tʃɹuθ, ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz duɪŋ əɹ bɛs tə əpɪɹ pɑɹɾ ʌv ə kæbənət bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔl. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ə daɪvɝʒən. "tɔɪ dʌzn min tə bi ɹud," tuɑn mɝmɝɾ ɪn ðət sloʊ hʌni dʒɹɔl. "hi dʒʌst əz nɛvɝ bɪn tʃɹeɪn ɪn mænɝz. bʌɾ ɪts leɪt, mæstɝ tʃɛɝɪn; taɪm fəɹ oʊlvɝ tə bi ɪn bɛd. pɝhæps jəl ɛskɔɹɾ ɪm tə hɪz tɛnt? wɪl pleɪ əɡɛn ənʌðɝ taɪm, oʊlvɝ. wəd jə laɪk mi tə titʃ jə tə pleɪ stoʊnz?" oʊlvɝ moʊst ɛmfæɾɪkli wʊd. hi ɔlmoʊst ɹɪəld, seɪɪŋ soʊ. ðə bɔɪ laɪkt ɛniθɪŋ ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃæns tə smaɪl əɾ ə wʊmən, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə tʃæns tə seɪ θɪŋz ðət ʃʊɾə ɡɑɾən ɪm slæp tɪl ɪz ɪɹz swɛld ʌp bɪɡɝ ðən ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi wɝ. ɪf mæt ɛvɝ faʊn aʊt wɪtʃ ə hɪz 'ʌŋkəlz' wɑz titʃɪŋ ɪm ðæt. . . . bʌt ðə læd ɡæðɝd ðə pisəz ə hɪz ɡeɪm ən kɛɹfəli ɹoʊld ʌp ðə laɪn-mɑɹkt klɔθ wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛkən ɝdʒɪŋ. hi ivən meɪɾ ə vɛɹi ɡʊd lɛɡ, θæŋkɪŋ ðə haɪ leɪɾi, bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ noʊl lɛɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə wæɡən. mæt nɑɾəd əpɹuvɪŋli. hi hæd tɔt ðə bɔɪ haʊ tə meɪk ə lɛɡ, bʌt ðə bɔɪ juʒəwəli æɾəd ə lɪɹ fəɹ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən. ɪf i ɛvɝ faʊn aʊt hu. . . . "ju hæv ə ɹizən fəɹ ɪntɝʌptɪŋ mi, tɔɪ?" tuɑn sɛɾ ɪn kul toʊnz. "ɪɾ ɪz leɪt, ən aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ tə slip." hi meɪɾ ə lɛɡ ən ɡeɪv əɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl. hi kəd bi pəlaɪɾ ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ jə wɝ ɔl ɹaɪt. ðiz wæɡənz ɑɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl, ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. ən aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹən hæpi wɪð ðə kloʊðz aɪ kəd faɪn ju. aɪ θɔt ðɪs maɪt meɪk jə fil ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ." fɪʃɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ bæɡ fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, hi pɹizɛntəɾ ɪt wɪð ə flɝɪʃ. wɪmən ɔlweɪz laɪk ðət lɪɾəl ɛkstʃɹə flɝɪʃ.

Tuon looked up at him through her eyelashes, a black porcelain doll in a dress that was too big for her. Light, but she had long lashes. She ignored Egeanin as if the other woman did not exist, and in truth, Egeanin was doing her best to appear part of a cabinet built into the wall. So much for hoping for a diversion. "Toy doesn't mean to be rude," Tuon murmured in that slow honey drawl. "He just has never been trained in manners. But it is late, Master Charin; time for Olver to be in bed. Perhaps you will escort him to his tent? We'll play again another time, Olver. Would you like me to teach you to play stones?" Olver most emphatically would. He almost wriggled, saying so. The boy liked anything that gave him a chance to smile at a woman, not to mention a chance to say things that should have gotten him slapped till his ears swelled up bigger than they already were. If Mat ever found out which of his 'uncles' was teaching him that. . . . But the lad gathered the pieces of his game and carefully rolled up the line-marked cloth without a second urging. He even made a very good leg, thanking the High Lady, before letting Noal lead him from the wagon. Mat nodded approvingly. He had taught the boy how to make a leg, but the boy usually added a leer for a pretty woman. If he ever found out who. . . . "You have a reason for interrupting me, Toy?" Tuon said in cool tones. "It is late, and I was thinking of going to sleep." He made a leg and gave her his best smile. He could be polite even if she was not. "I just wanted to make sure you were all right. These wagons are uncomfortable, on the road. And I know you aren't happy with the clothes I could find you. I thought this might make you feel a little better." Fishing the leather bag from his pocket, he presented it with a flourish. Women always liked that little extra flourish.

sɪlutʃə tɛnst, blu aɪz ʃɑɹpənɪŋ, bʌt tuɑn wæɡəld əɹ slɪm fɪŋɡɝz ən ðə boʊsəmi meɪd səbsaɪɾɪd. ə lɪɾəl. mæt laɪk faɪsti wɪmən, baɪ ən lɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi ɹuən ðɪs, hi wɑz gɑnə pæɾəl əɹ bɑɾəm. hi hʌŋ ɑn tə hɪz smaɪl wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ən ivən mænədʒ tə ɹætʃəɾ ɪɾ ʌp ə nɑtʃ.

Selucia tensed, blue eyes sharpening, but Tuon waggled her slim fingers and the bosomy maid subsided. A little. Mat liked feisty women, by and large, but if she ruined this, he was going to paddle her bottom. He hung on to his smile with an effort, and even managed to ratchet it up a notch.

tuɑn tɝn ðə bæɡ oʊvɝ əɹ hænz sɛvɹəl taɪmz bɪfɔɹ əntiɪŋ ðə dʒɹɔstʃɹɪŋz ən spɪlɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt kənteɪn ɪndə hɝ læp, ə hɛvi nɛkləs ʌv ɡoʊld ən kɑɹvd æmbɝ. ən ɪkspɛnsɪv pis, ən sintʃæn wɝk tə but. hi wɑz pɹaʊɾ ə faɪndɪŋ ðə θɪŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ən ækɹəbæt, hu hæɾ ɪt fɹəm ə sintʃæn ɔfəsɝ huz fænsi ʃi kɑt, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə sɛl naʊ ðəɾ əɹ ɔfəsɝ wɑz lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ɪt dɪd nɑt suɾ əɹ skɪn, wʌtɛvɝ ðət mɛnt. hi smaɪld ən weɪɾəd. dʒuəlz ɔlweɪz sɔfən ə wʊmənz hɑɹt.

Tuon turned the bag over her hands several times before untying the drawstrings and spilling what it contained into her lap, a heavy necklace of gold and carved amber. An expensive piece, and Seanchan work to boot. He was proud of finding the thing. It had been the property of an acrobat, who had it from a Seanchan officer whose fancy she caught, but she had been willing to sell now that her officer was left behind. It did not suit her skin, whatever that meant. He smiled and waited. Jewels always softened a woman's heart.

noʊ wʌnz ɹiækʃən wɑz kwaɪt wʌɾ i ɪkspɛktəd, ðoʊ. tuɑn lɪftəd ðə nɛkləs ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ feɪs wɪð boʊθ hænz, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin sətʃ ə θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ. sɪlutʃəz lɪp kɝld ɪn ə snɪɹ. sɛɾəl sɛɾ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi daʊn ɑn əɹ niz ən lʊkt ət hɪm, ðə lɑɹdʒ ɡoʊldən hups ɪn əɹ ɪɹz sweɪɪŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

No one's reaction was quite what he expected, though. Tuon lifted the necklace in front of her face with both hands, studying it as if she had never seen such a thing before. Selucia's lip curled in a sneer. Setalle set her embroidery down on her knees and looked at him, the large golden hoops in her ears swaying as she shook her head.

əbɹʌpli, tuɑn θɹʌs ðə nɛkləs bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ təwɔɹd sɪlutʃə. "ɪt dʌz nɑt sut mi," ʃi sɛd. "wʊd jə laɪk ɪt, sɪlutʃə?" mæts smaɪl slɪpt ə lɪɾəl.

Abruptly, Tuon thrust the necklace back over her shoulder toward Selucia. "It does not suit me," she said. "Would you like it, Selucia?" Mat's smile slipped a little.

ðə kɹim-skɪnd wʊmən tʊk ðə nɛkləs bɪtwin θʌm ən fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ, əz ɪf hoʊldɪŋ ə dɛd ɹæt baɪ ðə teɪl. "ə pis fəɹ ə ʃeɪ dænsɝ tə wɛɹ wɪð əɹ veɪl," ʃi sɛd ɹaɪli. wɪð ə twɪst ə hɝ ɹɪst, ʃi hɝl ðə nɛkləs əɾ ɛdʒiənɪn, snæpɪŋ, "pʊɾ ɪɾ ɑn!" ɛdʒiənɪn kɑt ðə θɪŋ dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ɪt hɪɾ əɹ feɪs. mæts smaɪl slɪd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ ɔf hɪz.

The cream-skinned woman took the necklace between thumb and forefinger, as if holding a dead rat by the tail. "A piece for a shea dancer to wear with her veil," she said wryly. With a twist of her wrist, she hurled the necklace at Egeanin, snapping, "Put it on!" Egeanin caught the thing just before it hit her face. Mat's smile slid the rest of the way off his.

hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ən ɪksploʊʒən, bʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ɪmiɾiətli fʌmbəld oʊpən ðə klæsp ən pʊʃt əɹ hɛvi wɪɡ bæk tə fæsən ɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ nɛk. hɝ feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn moʊldəd fɹəm snoʊ fəɹ ɔl ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪt.

He expected an explosion, but Egeanin immediately fumbled open the clasp and pushed her heavy wig back to fasten it behind her neck. Her face might have been molded from snow for all the expression on it.

"tɝn," sɪlutʃə kəmændəd, ən ɪt wɑz ə kəmænd, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt. "lɛt mi si." ɛdʒiənɪn tɝnd. stɪf əz ə fɛns poʊst, bʌt ʃi tɝnd. sɛɾəl lʊkt əɾ əɹ ɪntɛnli, wɪð ə pʌzəld ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ðən ɡeɪv mæt ə dɪfɹən hɛd ʃeɪk bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. wɪmən hæɾ əz mɛni weɪz ə ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz əz ðeɪ hæd lʊks. ðɪs wʌn sɛɾ i wɑz ə ful, ən ɪf i dɪd nɑt kætʃ ðə faɪnɝ nuɑnsɪz, hi wɑz dʒʌst əz ɡlæd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wʊɾə laɪk ðɛm. bɝn hɪm, hi bɑɾ ə nɛkləs fəɹ tuɑn, hu ɡeɪv ɪt tə sɪlutʃə ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən naʊ ɪt wɑz ɛdʒiənɪnz?

"Turn," Selucia commanded, and it was a command, without any doubt. "Let me see." Egeanin turned. Stiff as a fence post, but she turned. Setalle looked at her intently, with a puzzled shake of her head, then gave Mat a different head shake before returning to her embroidery. Women had as many ways of shaking their heads as they had looks. This one said he was a fool, and if he did not catch the finer nuances, he was just as glad. He did not think he would have liked them. Burn him, he bought a necklace for Tuon, who gave it to Selucia right in front of him, and now it was Egeanin's?

"ʃi keɪm fəɹ ə nu neɪm," tuɑn sɛd mjuzɪŋli. "wʌt dʌz ʃi kɔl hɝsɛlf?"

"She came for a new name," Tuon said musingly. "What does she call herself?"

"laɪlwɪn," sɪlutʃə ɹɪplaɪd. "ə fɪɾɪŋ neɪm fəɹ ə ʃeɪ dænsɝ. laɪlwɪn ʃɪpləs, pɝhæps?" tuɑn nɑɾəd. "laɪlwɪn ʃɪpləs."

"Leilwin," Selucia replied. "A fitting name for a shea dancer. Leilwin Shipless, perhaps?" Tuon nodded. "Leilwin Shipless."

ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɝkt əz ðoʊ ɛvɹi wɝd wɑz ə slæp. "meɪ aɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ?" ʃi æsk stɪfli, bɛndɪŋ ɪn ʃɑɹp baʊ.

Egeanin jerked as though every word was a slap. "May I withdraw?" she asked stiffly, bending in sharp bow.

"ɪf jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, ðən ɡoʊ," mæt ɡɹaʊld. bɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs hæd nɑt bɪn ðə bɛs noʊʃən i ɛvɝ hæd, bʌt meɪbi hi kəd ɹɪkʌvɝ ə lɪɾəl wɪθaʊt hɝ.

"If you want to go, then go," Mat growled. Bringing her in the first place had not been the best notion he ever had, but maybe he could recover a little without her.

aɪz lɑkt ɑn ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz, ɛdʒiənɪn sæŋk tə hɝ niz. "pliz, meɪ aɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ?" tuɑn sæt ðəɹ stʃɹeɪt-bækt ɑn ðə flɔɹ stɛɹɪŋ θɹu ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən, klɪɹli nɑt siɪŋ əɹ əɾ ɔl. sɪlutʃə aɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪn ʌp ən daʊn, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps. sɛɾəl pʊʃt əɹ niɾəl θɹu ðə klɔθ stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn əɹ hup. noʊ wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst ət mæt. ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɹɑp tə hɝ feɪs, ən mæt bɪt bæk ə stɑɹɾəld oʊθ wən ʃi kɪs ðə flɔɹ. "pliz," ʃi sɛd hɔɹsli, "aɪ bɛɡ liv tə wɪðdʒɹɔ."

Eyes locked on the floorboards, Egeanin sank to her knees. "Please, may I withdraw?" Tuon sat there straight-backed on the floor staring through the taller woman, clearly not seeing her at all. Selucia eyed Egeanin up and down, pursing her lips. Setalle pushed her needle through the cloth stretched on her hoop. No one so much as glanced at Mat. Egeanin dropped to her face, and Mat bit back a startled oath when she kissed the floor. "Please," she said hoarsely, "I beg leave to withdraw."

"ju wɪl ɡoʊ, laɪlwɪn," sɪlutʃə sɛd, koʊld əz ə kwin spikɪŋ tə ə tʃɪkɪnθif, "æn jəl nɑt lemi si jəɹ feɪs əɡɛn ənlɛs ɪts kʌvɝd baɪ ə ʃeɪ dænsɝz veɪl." ɛdʒiənɪn skɹæmbəl bækwɝɾ ɑn hænz ən niz ən ɔl bʌt tʌmbəld aʊt ðə dɔɹ, soʊ fæs ðət mæt wɑz lɛft ɡeɪpɪŋ. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, hi mænədʒ tə ɹɪɡeɪn ɪz smaɪl. ðəɹ sim lɪɾəl pɔɪn ɪn steɪɪŋ, bʌɾ ə mæn kəd meɪk ə ɡɹeɪsfəl ɛɡzɪt.

"You will go, Leilwin," Selucia said, cold as a queen speaking to a chickenthief, "and you will not let me see your face again unless it is covered by a shea dancer's veil." Egeanin scrambled backward on hands and knees and all but tumbled out the door, so fast that Mat was left gaping. With an effort, he managed to regain his smile. There seemed little point in staying, but a man could make a graceful exit.

"wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz - "

"Well, I suppose - "

tuɑn ɹɪəld əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛn, stɪl nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ən sɪlutʃə kʌɾ ɪm ʃɔɹt. "ðə haɪ leɪɾi ɪz wɪɹi, tɔɪ. juv əɹ pɝmɪʃən tə ɡoʊ."

Tuon wriggled her fingers again, still not looking at him, and Selucia cut him short. "The High Lady is weary, Toy. You have her permission to go."

"lʊk, maɪ neɪm ɪz mæt," hi sɛd. "æn izi neɪm. ə sɪmpəl neɪm. mæt." tuɑn maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə pɔɹsələn dɑl ɪn tʃɹuθ fəɹ ɔl ðə ɹɪspɑns ʃi meɪd.

"Look, my name is Mat," he said. "An easy name. A simple name. Mat." Tuon might as well have been a porcelain doll in truth for all the response she made.

sɛɾəl sɛt daʊn əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ðoʊ, ən ɹoʊz wɪð wʌn hæn ɹɛstɪŋ laɪtli ɑn ðə hɪlt ə ðə kɝv dæɡɝ stʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt. "jʌŋ mæn, ɪf jə θɪŋk jəɹ gɑnə laʊnʒ əbaʊt tɪl jə ɡɛt tə si əs ɹɛɾiɪŋ fəɹ bɛd, jəɹ sædli mɪsteɪkən." ʃi smaɪl seɪɪŋ ɪt, bʌt ʃi dɪɾ əv əɹ hæn ɑn əɹ naɪf, ən ʃi wɑz ɛbu dɑɹi ɪnʌf tə stɪk ə mæn ɑn ə wɪm. tuɑn ɹɪmeɪn ən ənmoʊvɪŋ dɑl, ə kwin ɑn əɹ θɹoʊn sʌmhaʊ mɪsteɪkənli dʒɹɛst ɪn ɪl-fɪɾɪŋ kloʊðz. mæt lɛft.

Setalle set down her embroidery, though, and rose with one hand resting lightly on the hilt of the curved dagger stuck behind her belt. "Young man, if you think you're going to lounge about till you get to see us readying for bed, you're sadly mistaken." She smiled saying it, but she did have her hand on her knife, and she was Ebou Dari enough to stick a man on a whim. Tuon remained an unmoving doll, a queen on her throne somehow mistakenly dressed in ill-fitting clothes. Mat left.

ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz linɪŋ ɑn wʌn hæn əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən, hɝ hɛd hæŋɪŋ. hɝ ʌðɝ hænd wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə nɛkləs ɝaʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. hɑɹnən muvd, ə lɪɾəl weɪ ɔf ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, dʒʌs tə ʃoʊ hi wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. ə waɪz mæn, tə kip klɪɹ ʌv ɛdʒiənɪn dʒʌs ðɛn. mæt wɑz tu ɪɹəteɪɾəd fəɹ wɪzdəm. "wʌt wɑz ðəɾ əbaʊt?" hi dɪmændəd. "ju doʊn əv tə ɡoʊ ɑn jəɹ niz tə tuɑn ɛnimɔɹ.

Egeanin was leaning on one hand against the side of the wagon, her head hanging. Her other hand was gripping the necklace around her throat. Harnan moved, a little way off in the darkness, just to show he was still there. A wise man, to keep clear of Egeanin just then. Mat was too irritated for wisdom. "What was that about?" he demanded. "You don't have to go on your knees to Tuon anymore.

ən sɪlutʃə? ʃiz ə blʌɾi leɪɾiz meɪd! aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛnibəɾi hud dʒʌmp fəɹ ɪz kwin ðə weɪ jə dʒʌmp fəɹ hɝ."

And Selucia? She's a bloody lady's maid! I don't know anybody who'd jump for his queen the way you jumped for her."

ɛdʒiənɪnz hɑɹd feɪs wɑz ʃæɾoʊd, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz hæɡɝd. "ðə haɪ leɪɾi ɪz . . . hu ʃi ɪz. sɪlutʃə ɪz əɹ sɔɪhɪn. noʊ wʌn ə ðə loʊ blʌd wəd dɛɹ miɾ əɹ sɔɪhɪnz aɪz, ən meɪbi nɑt ðə haɪ blʌd, iðɝ." ðə klæsp bɹoʊk wɪð ə mətælɪk snæp əz ʃi dʒɝk ðə nɛkləs fɹi. "bʌt ðɛn, aɪm nɑɾ ʌv ɛni blʌd, naʊ." ɹɪɹɪŋ bæk, ʃi pʊɾ əɹ hoʊl bɑɾi ɪndə θɹoʊɪŋ ðə nɛkləs əz fɑɹ ɪndə ðə naɪɾ əz ʃi kʊd.

Egeanin's hard face was shadowed, but her voice was haggard. "The High Lady is . . . who she is. Selucia is her so'jhin. No one of the low Blood would dare meet her so'jhin's eyes, and maybe not the High Blood, either." The clasp broke with a metallic snap as she jerked the necklace free. "But then, I'm not of any Blood, now." Rearing back, she put her whole body into throwing the necklace as far into the night as she could.

mæt oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. hi cʊɾə bɑɾ ə dʌzən pɹaɪm hɔɹsəz wɪð wʌɾ i peɪd fəɹ ðət θɪŋ ən hæd kɔɪn lɛft. hi kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ə wɝd. hi maɪt nɑɾ ɔlweɪz bi waɪz, bʌɾ i wɑz waɪz ɪnʌf tə noʊ wən ə wʊmən ɹɪli maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə stɪk ə naɪf ɪn hɪm. hi nu ənʌðɝ θɪŋ, əz wɛl. ɪf ɛdʒiənɪn bɪheɪv ðɪs weɪ ɝaʊn tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə, ðən i hæd bɛɾɝ meɪk ʃʊɹ ðə sʌldəm wɝ kɛp klɪɹ. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌt ðeɪ wəd də ɪf tuɑn stɑɹɾəd wɪɡəlɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ðət lɛft ɪm wɪð ə dʒɑb ʌv wɝk tə du. wɛl, hi heɪɾəd wɝk, bʌt ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz hæɾ ɪz hɛd stʌft fʊl ə bæɾəlz. hi heɪɾəd bæɾəl, tu - ə mæn kəd ɡɛt kɪl dɛd! - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən wɝk. stʃɹæɾədʒi ən tæktɪks. lɝn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, lɝn jəɹ ɛnəmi, ən ɪf jə kəd nɑt wɪn wʌn weɪ, jə faʊn ənʌðɝ. ðə nɛks naɪɾ i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pɝpəl wæɡən, əloʊn, ən wʌns oʊlvɝ hæd fɪnɪʃt ɪz lɛsən ɪn stoʊnz fɹəm tuɑn, mæt ɪnveɪiɡəld ɪz weɪ ɪndə ə ɡeɪm. ət fɝst, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ əkɹɔs ðə bɔɹd fɹəm ðə dɑɹk lɪɾəl wʊmən, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ tə wɪn əɹ luz. səm wɪmən laɪk tə wɪn ɛvɹi taɪm, bʌt ðə mæn hæd tə meɪk əɹ wɝk fəɹ ɪt. səm laɪk ðə mæn tə wɪn, əɹ ət lis mɔɹ ɔfən ðən i lɔst. niðɝ meɪɾ ɛni sɛns tə hɪm - hi laɪk tə wɪn, ən ði iziɝ, ðə bɛɾɝ - bʌt ðət wɑz haʊ ɪt wɑz. waɪl i wɑz dɪðɝɪŋ, tuɑn tʊk mæɾɝz aʊɾ ə hɪz hænz. hæfweɪ θɹu ðə ɡeɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæɾ ɪm ɪn ə tʃɹæp i kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv. hɝ waɪt stoʊnz wɝ kʌɾɪŋ ɔf ɪz blæk ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ə klin ən ɹisaʊndɪŋ wɪn fəɹ hɝ.

Mat opened his mouth. He could have bought a dozen prime horses with what he paid for that thing and had coin left. He closed it again without saying a word. He might not always be wise, but he was wise enough to know when a woman really might try to stick a knife in him. He knew another thing, as well. If Egeanin behaved this way around Tuon and Selucia, then he had better make sure the sul'dam were kept clear. The Light only knew what they would do if Tuon started wiggling her fingers. That left him with a job of work to do. Well, he hated work, but those old memories had his head stuffed full of battles. He hated battle, too - a man could get killed dead! - but it was better than work. Strategy and tactics. Learn the ground, learn your enemy, and if you could not win one way, you found another. The next night he returned to the purple wagon, alone, and once Olver had finished his lesson in stones from Tuon, Mat inveigled his way into a game. At first, sitting on the floor across the board from the dark little woman, he was not sure whether to win or lose. Some women liked to win every time, but the man had to make her work for it. Some liked the man to win, or at least more often than he lost. Neither made any sense to him - he liked to win, and the easier, the better - but that was how it was. While he was dithering, Tuon took matters out of his hands. Halfway through the game, he realized she had him in a trap he could not get out of. Her white stones were cutting off his black everywhere. It was a clean and resounding win for her.

"ju doʊn pleɪ vɛɹi wɛl, tɔɪ," ʃi sɛd mɑkəŋli. dɪspaɪt ðə toʊn, hɝ bɪɡ, lɪkwəɾ aɪz kənsɪɾɝd ɪm kuli, weɪɪŋ ən mɛʒɝɪŋ. ə mæn kəd dʒɹaʊn ɪn aɪz laɪk ðæt. hi smaɪld ən meɪɾ ɪz ɡʊdbaɪz bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ kəd bi ɛni θɔɾ ə kɪkɪŋ ɪm aʊt. stʃɹæɾədʒi. θɪŋk tə ðə fjutʃɝ.

"You don't play very well, Toy," she said mockingly. Despite the tone, her big, liquid eyes considered him coolly, weighing and measuring. A man could drown in eyes like that. He smiled and made his goodbyes before there could be any thought of kicking him out. Strategy. Think to the future.

də ði ʌnɪkspɛktɪd. ðə nɛks naɪt, hi bɹɔɾ ə smɔl ɹɛd peɪpɝ flaʊɝ meɪd baɪ wʌn ə ðə ʃoʊz simstʃɹəsəz. ən pɹizɛntəɾ ɪt tə ə stɑɹɾəld sɪlutʃə. sɛɾəlz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz, ən ivən tuɑn sim teɪkən əbæk. tæktɪks. pʊt jəɹ əpoʊnən ɔf bæləns. kʌm tə θɪŋk, wɪmən ən bæɾəlz wɝ nɑt ðət dɪfɹənt. boʊθ ɹæpt ə mæn ɪn fɑɡ ən kəɾ ɪm kɪl ɪm wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ. ɪf i wɑz kɛɹləs. ɛvɹi naɪɾ i vɪzəɾəd ðə pɝpəl wæɡən fəɹ ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz ʌndɝ sɛɾəl ən sɪlutʃəz wɑtʃfəl aɪz, ən i kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə kɹɔʃætʃt bɔɹd. tuɑn wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊd, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl tu izi tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf wɑtʃɪŋ ðə weɪ ʃi pleɪst əɹ stoʊnz, wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz bɛn bæk ɪn ə kjʊɹiəsli ɡɹeɪsfəl weɪ. ʃi wɑz juz tə hævɪŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ən ɪntʃ lɔŋ ən teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ nɑt tə bɹeɪk ðɛm. hɝ aɪz wɝ ə deɪnʒɝ, tu.

Do the unexpected. The next night, he brought a small red paper flower made by one of the show's seamstresses. And presented it to a startled Selucia. Setalle's eyebrows rose, and even Tuon seemed taken aback. Tactics. Put your opponent off balance. Come to think, women and battles were not that different. Both wrapped a man in fog and could him kill him without trying. If he was careless. Every night he visited the purple wagon for a game of stones under Setalle and Selucia's watchful eyes, and he concentrated on the crosshatched board. Tuon was very good, and it was all too easy to find himself watching the way she placed her stones, with her fingers bent back in a curiously graceful way. She was used to having fingernails an inch long and taking care not to break them. Her eyes were a danger, too.

jə niɾəd ə klɪɹ hɛɾ ɪn stoʊnz əɹ bæɾəl, ən əɹ ɡeɪz sim tə ɹitʃ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl. hi bʌkəl daʊn tə ðə ɡeɪm, ðoʊ, ən mænədʒ tə wɪn fɔɹ ə ðə nɛkst sɛvən, wɪð wʌn dʒɹɔ. tuɑn wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd wən ʃi wʌn ən dɪtɝmənd wən ʃi lɔst, wɪð nʌn ə ðə tɛmpɝ tæntʃɹəmz i hæd fɪɹd, noʊ skeɪðɪŋ kɑmɛns əsaɪd fɹəm ɪnsɪstɪŋ ɑn kɔlɪŋ ɪm tɔɪ, nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə ðəɾ aɪsi ɹiɡəl hoʊtʊɹ, əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ pleɪɪŋ ɛniweɪ. ʃi pjʊɹli ɛndʒɔɪd ðə ɡeɪm, læfɪŋ ɪɡzʌltənli wən ʃi pʊld ɪm ɪndə ə tʃɹæp, læfɪŋ ɪn dɪlaɪt wən i mænədʒd ə klɛvɝ pleɪsmən tə ɪskeɪp. ʃi simd ə dɪfɹənt wʊmən wʌns ʃi lɔs hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə stoʊnz bɔɹd.

You needed a clear head in stones or battle, and her gaze seemed to reach inside his skull. He buckled down to the game, though, and managed to win four of the next seven, with one draw. Tuon was satisfied when she won and determined when she lost, with none of the temper tantrums he had feared, no scathing comments aside from insisting on calling him Toy, not very much of that icy regal hauteur, as long as they were playing anyway. She purely enjoyed the game, laughing exultantly when she pulled him into a trap, laughing in delight when he managed a clever placement to escape. She seemed a different woman once she lost herself in the stones board.

ə flaʊɝ soʊn fɹəm blu lɪnən fɑloʊd ðə peɪpɝ blɑsəm, ən tu deɪz leɪɾɝ, ə pɪŋk sɪlk blum ðət spɹɛɾ aʊɾ əz waɪɾ əz ə wʊmənz pɑm. boʊθ hændəd tə sɪlutʃə. hɝ blu aɪz ɪnkɹisɪŋli sɛɾ ɪn ə səspɪʃəs fɹaʊn wən ðeɪ ɹɛstəɾ ɑn hɪm, bʌt tuɑn toʊld əɹ ʃi kəd kip ðə flaʊɝz, ən ʃi stɔɹɾ əm əweɪ kɛɹfəli, foʊldəɾ ɪn ə lɪnən klɔθ. hi lɛt θɹi deɪz pæs wɪθaʊɾ ə pɹɛzənt, ðən bɹɔɾ ə lɪɾəl klʌstɝ ə ɹɛd sɪlk ɹoʊzbʊdz, kəmplit wɪð ʃɔɹt stɛmz ən ɡlɪsnɪŋ livz ðət lʊkt əz ɹil əz neɪtʃɝ, oʊnli mɔɹ pɝfəkt. hi hæɾ æsk ðə simstʃɹɪs tə meɪk ɪɾ ɑn ðə deɪ hi bɑt ðət fɝs peɪpɝ flaʊɝ.

A flower sewn from blue linen followed the paper blossom, and two days later, a pink silk bloom that spread out as wide as a woman's palm. Both handed to Selucia. Her blue eyes increasingly set in a suspicious frown when they rested on him, but Tuon told her she could keep the flowers, and she stored them away carefully, folded in a linen cloth. He let three days pass without a present, then brought a little cluster of red silk rosebuds, complete with short stems and glistening leaves that looked as real as nature, only more perfect. He had asked the seamstress to make it on the day he bought that first paper flower.

sɪlutʃə tʊk ə stɛp, ɹitʃɪŋ tə æksɛp ðə ɹoʊzbʊdz wɪð ə kɝl tə hɝ lɪp, bʌɾ i sæt daʊn ən pʊt ðə flaʊɝz bɪsaɪd ðə bɔɹd, ə lɪɾəl təwɔɹd tuɑn. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌs lɛft ɪt laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ. ʃi nɛvɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænst əɾ ɪt. dɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə smɔl lɛðɝ bæɡz ðət hɛl ðə stoʊnz, hi plʌkt wʌn fɹəm itʃ ən ʃʌfəld əm bɪtwin ɪz hænz tɪl ivən i wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɪtʃ wɑz wɛɹ, ðən ɔfɝɾ ɪz kloʊz fɪsts. tuɑn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmənt, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪz feɪs wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən, ðən tæpt ɪz lɛf hænd. hi oʊpən ɪt tə dɪspleɪ ðə ɡlɪsnɪŋ waɪt stoʊn.

Selucia took a step, reaching to accept the rosebuds with a curl to her lip, but he sat down and put the flowers beside the board, a little toward Tuon. He said nothing, just left it lying there. She never so much as glanced at it. Dipping into the small leather bags that held the stones, he plucked one from each and shuffled them between his hands till even he was unsure which was where, then offered his closed fists. Tuon hesitated a moment, studying his face with no expression, then tapped his left hand. He opened it to display the glistening white stone.

"aɪv tʃeɪnʒd maɪ maɪnd, tɔɪ," ʃi mɝmɝd, pleɪsɪŋ ðə waɪt stoʊn kɛɹfəli ɑn ði ɪntɝsɛkʃən ə tu laɪnz nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə bɔɹd. "ju pleɪ vɛɹi wɛl." mæt blɪŋkt. kəd ʃi noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz ʌp tə? sɪlutʃə wɑz stændɪŋ ət tuɑnz bæk, simɪŋli əbzɔɹbd ɪn ði ɔlmoʊst ɛmpti bɔɹd. səteɪl tɝn ə peɪdʒ ɪn əɹ bʊk ən ʃɪftəɾ ə lɪɾəl tə ɡɛɾ ə bɛɾɝ laɪt. ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt stoʊnz. ɪf ʃi ivən səspɛktəɾ ɪz ɹil ɡeɪm, ʃi wəd tɔs ɪm aʊɾ ɑn ɪz ɪɹ. ɛni wʊmən wʊd. ɪt hæd tə bi ðə stoʊnz.

"I've changed my mind, Toy," she murmured, placing the white stone carefully on the intersection of two lines near the center of the board. "You play very well." Mat blinked. Could she know what he was up to? Selucia was standing at Tuon's back, seemingly absorbed in the almost empty board. Setaile turned a page in her book and shifted a little to get a better light. Of course not. She was talking about stones. If she even suspected his real game, she would toss him out on his ear. Any woman would. It had to be the stones.

ðət wɑz ðə naɪt ðeɪ pleɪd tə ə dʒɹɔ, wɪð itʃ ə ðɛm kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ hæf ðə bɔɹɾ ɪn ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ pulz ən pætʃəz. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi wʌn ə vɪktɝi.

That was the night they played to a draw, with each of them controlling half the board in irregular pools and patches. In truth, she won a victory.

"aɪ hæv kɛp maɪ wɝd, tɔɪ," ʃi dʒɹɔld əz i wɑz ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ ðə stoʊnz ɪn ðə bæɡz. "noʊ ətɛmps tə ɪskeɪp, noʊ ətɛmps ət bɪtʃɹeɪəl. ðɪs ɪz kənfaɪnɪŋ." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɝaʊn ət ði ɪntɪɹiɝ ə ðə wæɡən. "aɪ wɪʃ tə teɪk wɔks. æftɝ dɑɹk wɪl du. jə meɪ əkʌmpəni mi." hɝ aɪz tʌtʃt ðə klʌstɝ ə ɹoʊzbʊdz, ðən ɹoʊz tə hɪz feɪs. "tə meɪk ʃʊɹ aɪ doʊn ɹʌn əweɪ." səteɪl mɑɹkt əɹ pleɪs wɪð ə slɪm fɪŋɡɝ ən lʊkt ət hɪm.

"I have kept my word, Toy," she drawled as he was replacing the stones in the bags. "No attempts to escape, no attempts at betrayal. This is confining." She gestured around at the interior of the wagon. "I wish to take walks. After dark will do. You may accompany me." Her eyes touched the cluster of rosebuds, then rose to his face. "To make sure I don't run away." Setaile marked her place with a slim finger and looked at him.

sɪlutʃə stʊd bɪhaɪn tuɑn ən lʊkt ət hɪm. ðə wʊmən hæd kɛpt əɹ wɝd, mæɾ əz ðət simd. wɔks æftɝ dɑɹk, wɪð moʊst ə ðə ʃoʊfoʊk ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðɛɹ bɛdz, wəd də noʊ hɑɹm, nɑt wɪð ɪm ðəɹ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ. soʊ waɪ dɪɾ i fil ðəɾ i wɑz luzɪŋ kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən?

Selucia stood behind Tuon and looked at him. The woman had kept her word, mad as that seemed. Walks after dark, with most of the showfolk already in their beds, would do no harm, not with him there to make sure. So why did he feel that he was losing control of the situation?

tuɑn əɡɹid tə ɡoʊ kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd, wɪtʃ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə ɹɪlif. ðə blæk hɛɹ wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ bæk ɪn ɑn əɹ ʃeɪv skælp, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən lɔŋ fʌz, ən ənlaɪk sɪlutʃə, hu vɛɹi laɪkli slɛpt ɪn əɹ hɛd skɑɹf, tuɑn hæd ʃoʊn noʊ ɪnkləneɪʃən tə kʌvɝ əɹ hɛd. ə tʃaɪld-saɪzd wʊmən wɪð hɛɹ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɛni mæn nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ bɔld wʊɾə bɪn ɹɪmɑɹkt ivən ɪn ðə naɪt.

Tuon agreed to go cloaked and hooded, which was something of a relief. The black hair was growing back in on her shaved scalp, but so far it was little more than long fuzz, and unlike Selucia, who very likely slept in her head scarf, Tuon had shown no inclination to cover her head. A child-sized woman with hair shorter than any man not going bald would have been remarked even in the night.

sɛɾəl ən sɪlutʃə ɔlweɪz fɑloʊɾ əɾ ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ðə leɪɾiz meɪd tə kip ə pɹətɛktɪv aɪ ɑn əɹ mɪstʃɹəs ən sɛɾəl tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə meɪd. ət list, hi θɔt ðət wɑz haʊ ɪt wɑz. səmtaɪmz ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə tu ʌv əm wɝ ɑfli fɹɛnli fəɹ ɡɑɹɾ ən pɹɪznɝ. hi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd sɛɾəl kɔʃənɪŋ sɪlutʃə ðəɾ i wɑz ə ɹoʊɡ wɪð wɪmən, ə faɪn θɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə bi seɪɪŋ! ən sɪlutʃə hæd kɑmli ɹɪplaɪd ðəɾ əɹ leɪɾi wəd bɹeɪk ɪz ɑɹmz ɪf i ʃoʊɾ ɛni dɪsɹɪspɛkt, dʒʌst əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pɹɪznɝz əɾ ɔl.

Setalle and Selucia always followed at a little distance in the darkness, the lady's maid to keep a protective eye on her mistress and Setalle to keep an eye on the maid. At least, he thought that was how it was. Sometimes it seemed they were both watching him. The two of them were awfully friendly for guard and prisoner. He had overheard Setalle cautioning Selucia that he was a rogue with women, a fine thing for her to be saying! And Selucia had calmly replied that her lady would break his arms if he showed any disrespect, just as if they were not prisoners at all.

hi θɔt tə juz ðiz wɔks tə lɝn ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ əbaʊt tuɑn - ʃi dɪd nɑt tɔk mʌtʃ oʊvɝ ə stoʊnz bɔɹd - bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌɾ i æskt əɹ dɪflɛktɪŋ ðə sʌbʒɪkt, juʒəwəli tə hɪm.

He thought to use these walks to learn a little more about Tuon - she did not talk much over a stones board - but she had a way of ignoring what he asked or deflecting the subject, usually to him.

"ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ɔl fɔɹəsts ən fɑɹmz," hi sɛɾ əz ðeɪ stʃɹoʊld əlɔŋ ðə meɪn stʃɹiɾ ə ðə ʃoʊ. klaʊdz hɪd ðə mun, ən ðə kʌlɝfəl wæɡənz wɝ ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl dɑɹk ʃeɪps, ðə pɝfɔɹmɝz' plætfɔɹmz laɪnɪŋ ðə stʃɹit mɪɹli ʃædoʊz. "ɛvɹibɑɾi ɡɹoʊz təbæk ən ɹeɪzəz ʃip. maɪ fɑðɝ bɹidz kaʊz, tu, ən tʃɹeɪdz hɔɹsəz, bʌt moʊsli, ɪts təbæk ən ʃip fɹəm wʌn ɛn tə ði ʌðɝ."

"The Two Rivers is all forests and farms," he said as they strolled along the main street of the show. Clouds hid the moon, and the colorful wagons were indistinguishable dark shapes, the performers' platforms lining the street merely shadows. "Everybody grows tabac and raises sheep. My father breeds cows, too, and trades horses, but mostly, it's tabac and sheep from one end to the other."

"jɔɹ fɑðɝ tʃɹeɪdz hɔɹsəz," tuɑn mɝmɝd. "ænd wʌt dʒju du, tɔɪ?" hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə tu wɪmən ɡoʊstɪŋ əlɔŋ tɛn peɪsɪz bæk. sɛɾəl maɪt nɑt bi kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ, ɪf i kɛpt ɪz vɔɪs daʊn, bʌɾ i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə bi ɑnəst. bɪsaɪdz, ðə ʃoʊ wɑz dɛd kwaɪəɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ʃi maɪt hɪɹ, ən ʃi nu wʌɾ i hæd bɪn duɪŋ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. "ɪm ə ɡæmblɝ," hi sɛd. "maɪ fɑðɝ kɔl hɪmsɛlf ə ɡæmblɝ," tuɑn sɛd sɔfli. "hi daɪɾ ʌv ə bæd weɪdʒɝ." ən haʊ wɝ jə səpoʊz tə faɪn aʊt wʌt ðət mɛnt? ənʌðɝ naɪt, wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ə ɹoʊ ʌv ænəməl keɪdʒɪz, itʃ wʌn bɪl tə fɪl ən ɪntaɪɝ wæɡən, hi sɛd, "wʌt dʒju də fəɹ fʌn, tuɑn? dʒʌs kəz jə ɛndʒɔɪ ɪt. əsaɪd fɹəm pleɪɪŋ stoʊnz." hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil sɪlutʃə bɹɪsəlɪŋ əɾ ɪz jus ə hɝ neɪm fɹəm θɝɾi fiɾ əweɪ, bʌt tuɑn dɪd nɑt sim tə maɪnd. hi θɔt ʃi dɪd nɑt.

"Your father trades horses," Tuon murmured. "And what do you do, Toy?" He glanced over his shoulder at the two women ghosting along ten paces back. Setalle might not be close enough to hear, if he kept his voice down, but he decided to be honest. Besides, the show was dead quiet in the darkness. She might hear, and she knew what he had been doing in Ebou Dar. "I'm a gambler," he said. "My father called himself a gambler," Tuon said softly. "He died of a bad wager." And how were you supposed to find out what that meant? Another night, walking along a row of animal cages, each one built to fill an entire wagon, he said, "What do you do for fun, Tuon? Just because you enjoy it. Aside from playing stones." He could almost feel Selucia bristling at his use of her name from thirty feet away, but Tuon did not seem to mind. He thought she did not.

"aɪ tʃɹeɪn hɔɹsəz ən deɪmeɪn," ʃi sɛd, piɹɪŋ ɪndə ə keɪdʒ ðət hɛld ə slipɪŋ laɪən. ði ænəməl wɑz oʊnli ə lɑɹdʒ ʃædoʊ laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ bɪhaɪn ðə θɪk bɑɹz. "dʌz i ɹɪli hæv ə blæk meɪn?

"I train horses and damane," she said, peering into a cage that held a sleeping lion. The animal was only a large shadow lying on the straw behind the thick bars. "Does he really have a black mane?

ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ laɪənz wɪð blæk meɪnz ɪn ɔl ə sintʃæn." ʃi tʃɹeɪn deɪmeɪn? fəɹ fʌn? laɪt! "hɔɹsəz?

There are no lions with black manes in all of Seanchan." She trained damane? For fun? Light! "Horses?

wʌt kaɪndə hɔɹsəz?" ɪt maɪt bi wɔɹhɔɹsɪz, ɪf ʃi tʃɹeɪn blʌɾi deɪmeɪn. fəɹ fʌn.

What kind of horses?" It might be warhorses, if she trained bloody damane. For fun.

"mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən tɛlz mi jəɹ ə skaʊnʒɹəl, tɔɪ." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kul, nɑt koʊld. kəmpoʊzd. ʃi tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm, feɪs hɪɾən ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ə hɝ kaʊl. "haʊ mɛni wɪmən əv jə kɪst?" ðə laɪən woʊk ʌp ən kɔft, ə dip saʊnd ɡɛɹəntid tə ɹeɪz ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɛniwʌnz hɛd. tuɑn dɪd nɑɾ ivən flɪntʃ. "lʊks laɪk ɹeɪnz kʌmɪŋ əɡɛn," hi sɛd wikli. "sɪlutʃə wɪl əv maɪ haɪɾ ɪf aɪ ɡɛt jə bæk soʊkt." hi hɝɾ əɹ læf sɔfli. wʌt hæɾ i sɛd ðət wɑz fʌni?

"Mistress Anan tells me you're a scoundrel, Toy." Her voice was cool, not cold. Composed. She turned toward him, face hidden in the shadows of her cowl. "How many women have you kissed?" The lion woke up and coughed, a deep sound guaranteed to raise the hair on anyone's head. Tuon did not even flinch. "Looks like rain's coming again," he said weakly. "Selucia will have my hide if I get you back soaked." He heard her laugh softly. What had he said that was funny?

ðəɹ wɑz ə pɹaɪs tə peɪ, ʌv kɔɹs. meɪbi θɪŋz wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪz weɪ ən meɪbi nɑt, bʌt wən jə θɔt ðeɪ wɝ, ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə pɹaɪs.

There was a price to pay, of course. Maybe things were going his way and maybe not, but when you thought they were, there was always a price.

"bʌntʃ ə tʃæɾɝɪŋ mæɡpaɪz," hi kəmpleɪn tə ɛdʒiənɪn. ði æftɝnun sæɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, ə ɹɛd-ɡoʊl bɔl hæf hɪɾən baɪ klaʊdz, kæstɪŋ ðə ʃoʊ ɪn lɔŋ ʃædoʊz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹeɪn, fəɹ wʌns, ən ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə koʊl ðeɪ wɝ sɪɾɪŋ hʌntʃt bɪniθ ðə ɡɹin wæɡən ðeɪ ʃɛɹd, pleɪɪŋ stoʊnz ɪn pleɪn saɪɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn u wɔk baɪ. ə ɡʊd mɛni dɪd, mɛn hɝiɪŋ əbaʊt səm læst-mɪnət tʃɔɹ, tʃɪlʒɹən snætʃɪŋ ðə faɪnəl tʃæns tə ɹoʊl hups θɹu ðə mʌd pʌɾəlz ən tɔs bɔlz bɪfɔɹ naɪt fɛl. wɪmən hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ skɝts ʌp ɡlænst ət ðə wæɡən ɪn pæsɪŋ, ən ivən wən ðeɪ wɝ hʊɾɪd, mæt nu wʌt ðɛɹ ɪkspɹɛʃənz wɝ. hɑɹdli ə wʊmən ɪn ðə ʃoʊ wəd spik tə mæt kɔθən.

"Bunch of chattering magpies," he complained to Egeanin. The afternoon sat on the horizon, a red-gold ball half hidden by clouds, casting the show in long shadows. There was no rain, for once, and in spite of the cold they were sitting hunched beneath the green wagon they shared, playing stones in plain sight of anyone who walked by. A good many did, men hurrying about some last-minute chore, children snatching the final chance to roll hoops through the mud puddles and toss balls before night fell. Women holding their skirts up glanced at the wagon in passing, and even when they were hooded, Mat knew what their expressions were. Hardly a woman in the show would speak to Mat Cauthon.

ɪɹɪɾəbli, hi ɹæɾəld ðə blæk stoʊnz i hɛld ɡæðɝɾ ɪn ɪz lɛf hænd. "ðeɪl ɡɛt ðɛɹ ɡoʊld wən wi ɹitʃ luɡɹd. ðæts ɔl ðeɪ ɔt tə kɛɹ əbaʊt. ðeɪ ʃʊdn bi poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪndə maɪ bɪznəs."

Irritably, he rattled the black stones he held gathered in his left hand. "They'll get their gold when we reach Lugard. That's all they ought to care about. They shouldn't be poking their noses into my business."

"ju kən hɑɹdli bleɪm ðɛm," ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɹɔld, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə bɔɹd. "ju ən aɪ ɑɹ səpoʊz tə bi fliɪŋ lʌvɝz, bʌt jə spɛn mɔɹ taɪm wɪð . . . hɝ . . . ðən wɪð mi." ʃi stɪl hæd tʃɹʌbəl nɑt kɔlɪŋ tuɑn haɪ leɪɾi. "ju bɪheɪv laɪk ə mæn kɔɹɾɪŋ." ʃi ɹitʃt tə pleɪs əɹ stoʊn, ðən stɑpt wɪð əɹ hæn əbʌv ðə bɔɹd. "ju kæn θɪŋk ʃɪl kəmplit ðə sɛɹəmoʊni, kən ju? jə kæn bi ðət bɪɡ ə ful."

"You can hardly blame them," Egeanin drawled, studying the board. "You and I are supposed to be fleeing lovers, but you spend more time with . . . her . . . than with me." She still had trouble not calling Tuon High Lady. "You behave like a man courting." She reached to place her stone, then stopped with her hand above the board. "You can't think she'll complete the ceremony, can you? You can't be that big a fool."

"wʌt sɛɹəmoʊni? wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt?" "ju neɪmd əɹ jəɹ waɪf θɹi taɪmz ðət naɪɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "ju ɹɪli doʊnt noʊ? ə wʊmən sɛz θɹi taɪmz ðəɾ ə mæn ɪz əɹ hʌzbənd, ən i sɛz θɹi taɪmz ʃiz ɪz waɪf, ən ðəɹ mɛɹid. ðəɹ ɑɹ blɛsɪŋz ɪnvɑlvd, juʒəwəli, bʌɾ ɪts seɪɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wɪtnəsəz ðət meɪks ɪɾ ə mɛɹɪdʒ. jə ɹɪli dɪdnt noʊ?" mæt læft, ən ʃɹʌɡd ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, filɪŋ ðə naɪf hæŋɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz nɛk. ə ɡʊd naɪf ɡeɪv ə mæn ə filɪŋ ə kʌmfɝt. bʌɾ ɪz læf wɑz hɔɹs. "bʌt ʃi dɪdn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ." hi hæd blʌɾi wɛl bɪn stʌfɪŋ ə ɡæɡ ɪn əɹ maʊθ ət ðə taɪm! "soʊ wʌtɛvɝ aɪ sɛd, ɪt dʌzn min ɛniθɪŋ." bʌɾ i nu wʌɾ ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ. ʃʊɹ əz wɔɾɝ wɑz wɛt, hi nu. hi hæd bɪn toʊld u hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɛɹi.

"What ceremony? What are you talking about?" "You named her your wife three times that night in Ebou Dar," she said slowly. "You really don't know? A woman says three times that a man is her husband, and he says three times she's his wife, and they're married. There are blessings involved, usually, but it's saying it in front of witnesses that makes it a marriage. You really didn't know?" Mat laughed, and shrugged his shoulders, feeling the knife hanging behind his neck. A good knife gave a man a feeling of comfort. But his laugh was hoarse. "But she didn't say anything." He had bloody well been stuffing a gag in her mouth at the time! "So whatever I said, it doesn't mean anything." But he knew what Egeanin was going to say. Sure as water was wet, he knew. He had been told who he was going to marry.

"wɪð ðə blʌd, ɪts ə lɪɾəl dɪfɹənt. səmtaɪmz ə noʊbəl fɹəm wʌn ɛn ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ mɛɹiz ə noʊbəl fɹəm ði ʌðɝ. ən ɝeɪnʒd mɛɹɪdʒ. ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli nɛvɝ əz ɛni ʌðɝ kaɪnd. ðeɪ meɪ nɑt wɑnə weɪɾ əntɪl ðeɪ kən bi təɡɛðɝ, soʊ wʌn æknɑlɪdʒɪz ðə mɛɹɪdʒ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz, ən ði ʌðɝ wɛɹ i ɪz. əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ boʊθ spik ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wɪtnəsəz, ɪnsaɪɾ ə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ, ðə mɛɹɪdʒ ɪz liɡəl. jə tʃɹuli dɪdnt noʊ?"

"With the Blood, it's a little different. Sometimes a noble from one end of the Empire marries a noble from the other. An arranged marriage. The Imperial family never has any other kind. They may not want to wait until they can be together, so one acknowledges the marriage where she is, and the other where he is. As long as they both speak in front of witnesses, inside a year and a day, the marriage is legal. You truly didn't know?"

ʃʊɹ wɑz ʃʊɹ, bʌt ðə stoʊnz stɪl spɪl fɹəm ɪz hæn ɑntu ðə bɔɹd, baʊnsɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ.

Sure was sure, but the stones still spilled from his hand onto the board, bouncing everywhere.

ðə blʌɾi ɡɝl nu. meɪbi ʃi θɔt ðɪs hoʊl θɪŋ wɑz ən ædvɛntʃɝ, əɹ ə ɡeɪm. meɪbi ʃi θɔt biɪŋ kɪdnæpt wɑz əz mʌtʃ fʌn əz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ hɔɹsəz əɹ blʌɾi deɪmeɪnbækslæʃ bʌɾ i nu hi wɑz ə tʃɹaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə sɛt ðə hʊk.

The bloody girl knew. Maybe she thought this whole thing was an adventure, or a game. Maybe she thought being kidnapped was as much fun as training horses or bloody damane\ But he knew he was a trout waiting for her to set the hook.

hi steɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə pɝpəl wæɡən fəɹ tu deɪz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ jus ɹʌnɪŋ - hi ɔlɹɛɾi hæd ðə blʌɾi hʊk ɪn ɪz maʊθ, ən i hæd pʊɾ ɪt ðəɹ hɪmsɛlf - bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə swɑloʊ ðə fleɪmɪŋ θɪŋ. oʊnli, hi nu ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə mæɾɝ ʌv wən ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dʒɝk ðə laɪn taɪt.

He stayed away from the purple wagon for two days. There was no use running - he already had the bloody hook in his mouth, and he had put it there himself - but he did not have to swallow the flaming thing. Only, he knew it was just a matter of when she decided to jerk the line tight.

əz sloʊli əz ðə ʃoʊ muvd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə fɛɹi əkɹɔs ði ɪldɑɹ, ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ælkɪnʒɹ ɑn ðə wɛs bæŋk tə kɔɹəmən ɑn ði ist, taɪɾi lɪɾəl wɔl taʊnz ə taɪl-ɹuf stoʊn bɪldɪŋz wɪð hæf ə dʌzən stoʊn dɑks itʃ. ðə sʌn wɑz klaɪmɪŋ haɪ, hɑɹdli ə klaʊd kɹɔs ðə skaɪ, ən ðoʊz waɪɾ əz nuwɑʃt wʊl. noʊ ɹeɪn tədeɪ, meɪbi. ɪt wɑz ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt kɹɔsɪŋ, wɪð tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ʃɪps fɹəm ʌpɹɪvɝ taɪd tə səm ə ðə dɑks ən bɪɡ bɑɹdʒ-laɪk fɛɹiz kɹɔlɪŋ fɹəm wʌn taʊn tə ði ʌðɝ ɑn lɔŋ swips. ðə sintʃæn əpɛɹənli θɔt soʊ, tu. ðeɪ hæd mɪlətɛɹi kæmps aʊtsaɪd boʊθ taʊnz, ən fɹəm ðə stoʊn wɔlz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹaɪz ɝaʊn ðə kæmps ən ðə stoʊn stʃɹʌktʃɝz ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ɪnsaɪd, ðeɪ hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə livɪŋ sun.

As slowly as the show moved, eventually they reached the ferry across the Eldar, running from Alkindar on the west bank to Coramen on the east, tidy little walled towns of tile-roofed stone buildings with half a dozen stone docks each. The sun was climbing high, hardly a cloud crossed the sky, and those white as newwashed wool. No rain today, maybe. It was an important crossing, with trading ships from upriver tied to some of the docks and big barge-like ferries crawling from one town to the other on long sweeps. The Seanchan apparently thought so, too. They had military camps outside both towns, and from the stone walls beginning to rise around the camps and the stone structures going up inside, they had no intention of leaving soon.

mæt kɹɔst oʊvɝ wɪð ðə fɝst wæɡənz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ pɪps. ðə bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ lʊkt ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪnʌf tə ən ʌndɪsɝnɪŋ aɪ; ɪt wəd nɑt sim aʊɾ ə pleɪs fəɹ ɪm tə bi ɹɪɾən baɪ ə fɛloʊ ɪn ə ɹʌf wʊlən koʊt wɪð ə wʊlən kæp pʊl daʊn oʊvɝ ɪz ɪɹz əɡɛns ðə koʊld. hi wɑz nɑɾ æktʃəli  kənsɪɾɝɪŋ meɪkɪŋ ə ɹʌn fəɹ ðə hɪli wʊɾɪd ɹɪdʒ kʌntʃɹi bɪhaɪn kɔɹəmən. θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt nɑt ɹɪli kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. ʃi gɑnə tə sɛt ðə hʊk wɛðɝ i ɹæn əɹ nɑt. soʊ hi sæt pɪps ət ði ɛn ʌv wʌn ə ðə stoʊn fɛɹi lændɪŋz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ʃoʊ kɹɔs oʊvɝ ən tʃɹʌndəl əweɪ θɹu ðə taʊn. ðəɹ wɝ sintʃæn ɑn ðə lændɪŋz, ə skwɑɾ ə bifi mɛn ɪn sɛɡmɛntɪɾ ɑɹmɝ peɪntəd blu ən bɝnt ɡoʊld ʌndɝ ə lin jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ wɪð wʌn θɪn blu plum ɑn ɪz ɑd-lʊkɪŋ hɛlmət. ðeɪ sim tə bi ðəɹ dʒʌs tə kip ɔɹɾɝ, bʌt ði ɔfəsɝ tʃɛk lukəz hɔɹs wɔɹənt, ən lukə ɪnkwaɪɝd wɛðɝ ðə noʊbəl lɔɹd maɪt noʊ ʌv ɡɹaʊn aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn suɾəbəl fəɹ ɪz ʃoʊ tə pɝfɔɹm. mæt kəɾ əv wɛpt. hi kəd si soʊlʒɝz wɛɹɪŋ stʃɹaɪpt ɑɹmɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪhaɪn hɪm, wɑndɝɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ʃɑps ən tævɝnz. ə ɹeɪkən swup daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ ɑn lɔŋ, ɹɪbd wɪŋz, əlaɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd wʌn ə ðə kæmps əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ ə ðə sneɪk-nɛkt kɹitʃɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðəɹ hæd tə bi hʌnʒɹədz ə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ðoʊz kæmps. meɪbi ə θaʊzənd. ən lukə gɑnə tə pʊɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊ. ðən wʌn ə ðə fɛɹiz hɪt ðə ɹoʊp-pæɾəd bʌmpɝz ət ði ɛn ə ðə lændɪŋ, ən ðə ɹæmp keɪm daʊn tə lɛt ðə wɪndoʊləs pɝpəl wæɡən ɹʌmbəl ɔf ɑntu ðə stoʊnz. sɛɾəl wɑz dʒɹaɪvɪŋ. sɪlutʃə sæɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ, piɹɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə hʊɾ ʌv ə feɪɾəd ɹɛd kloʊk. ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, swɑðd ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk soʊ nɑɾ ən ɪntʃ ə hɝ ʃoʊd, wɑz tuɑn.

Mat crossed over with the first wagons, riding Pips. The brown gelding looked ordinary enough to an undiscerning eye; it would not seem out of place for him to be ridden by a fellow in a rough woolen coat with a woolen cap pulled down over his ears against the cold. He was not actually considering making a run for the hilly wooded ridge country behind Coramen. Thinking about it, but not really considering. She was going to set the hook whether he ran or not. So he sat Pips at the end of one of the stone ferry landings, watching the show cross over and trundle away through the town. There were Seanchan on the landings, a squad of beefy men in segmented armor painted blue and burnt gold under a lean young officer with one thin blue plume on his odd-looking helmet. They seemed to be there just to keep order, but the officer checked Luca's horse warrant, and Luca inquired whether the noble lord might know of ground outside the town suitable for his show to perform. Mat could have wept. He could see soldiers wearing striped armor in the street behind him, wandering in and out of shops and taverns. A raken swooped down out of the sky on long, ribbed wings, alighting outside one of the camps across the river. Three or four of the snake-necked creatures were already on the ground. There had to be hundreds of soldiers in those camps. Maybe a thousand. And Luca was going to put on his show. Then one of the ferries hit the rope-padded bumpers at the end of the landing, and the ramp came down to let the windowless purple wagon rumble off onto the stones. Setalle was driving. Selucia sat on one side of her, peering out from the hood of a faded red cloak. On the other side, swathed in a dark cloak so not an inch of her showed, was Tuon.

mæt θɔɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ gɑnə fɔl aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. ɪf ɪz hɑɹt dɪd nɑt paʊn ɪts weɪ aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛs fɝst. ðə daɪs hæd stɑɹɾəd ʌp ɪn ɪz hɛd, ðət ɹætlɪŋ fil ə daɪs ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ə teɪbəl. ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə kʌm ʌp ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz, ðɪs taɪm; hi dʒʌs nu ɪt.

Mat thought his eyes were going to fall out of his head. If his heart did not pound its way out of his chest first. The dice had started up in his head, that rattling feel of dice rolling across a table. They were going to come up the Dark One's eyes, this time; he just knew it.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də ɪksɛp fɔl ɪn bɪsaɪd ðə pɝpəl wæɡən, ðoʊ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ əz ðoʊ laɪf wɝ wʌndɝfəl, ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə waɪd meɪn stʃɹit θɹu kɹɪɝz fəɹ ʃɑps ən hɔkɝz sɛlɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm tʃɹeɪz. ən sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪn fɔɹmeɪʃən naʊ, ən ðeɪ aɪd ðə bɹaɪtli peɪntəd wæɡənz wɪð ɪntʃɹəst. ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ tuɑn tə ʃaʊt. ʃi hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd, bʌɾ ə pɹɪznɝ wəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ tə ɡɛt ðə ʃækəlz lusənd. ɔl ʃi hæd tə də wɑz ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs, ən sʌmən ə θaʊzən sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz fəɹ ɹɛskju. ðə daɪs baʊnst ən spʌn ɪn mæts hɛd.

There was nothing to do except fall in beside the purple wagon, though, riding along as though life were wonderful, riding along the wide main street through criers for shops and hawkers selling things from trays. And Seanchan soldiers. They were not marching in formation now, and they eyed the brightly painted wagons with interest. Riding along and waiting for Tuon to shout. She had given her word, but a prisoner would say anything to get the shackles loosened. All she had to do was raise her voice, and summon a thousand Seanchan soldiers for rescue. The dice bounced and spun in Mat's head.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz.

Riding along, waiting for the Dark One's eyes.

tuɑn nɛvɝ spoʊk ə wɝd. ʃi pikt kjʊɹiəsli pæs ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ dip kaʊl, kjʊɹiəsli ən kɔʃəsli, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs hɪɾən, ən ivən əɹ hænz, ɔl ɹæpt ɪn ðət dɑɹk kloʊk ən ivən hʌɾəlɪŋ əɡɛnst sɛɾəl laɪk ə tʃaɪl sikɪŋ ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə hɝ mʌðɝ ɪn ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹaʊd. nɛvɝ ə wɝɾ əntɪl ðeɪ hæd pæs ðə ɡeɪts ə kɔɹəmən ən wɝ ɹʌmbəlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə beɪs ə ðə ɹɪdʒ ðət ɹoʊz bɪhaɪn ðə taʊn, wɛɹ lukə wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə ʃoʊz wæɡənz. ðət wɑz wən mæt ɹɪli nu ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪskeɪp fəɹ hɪm. ʃi wɑz gɑnə sɛt ðə hʊk ɔl ɹaɪt. ʃi wɑz dʒʌs baɪɾɪŋ əɹ blʌɾi taɪm.

Tuon never spoke a word. She peeked curiously past the edge of her deep cowl, curiously and cautiously, but she kept her face hidden, and even her hands, all wrapped in that dark cloak and even huddling against Setalle like a child seeking the protection of her mother in a strange crowd. Never a word until they had passed the gates of Coramen and were rumbling toward the base of the ridge that rose behind the town, where Luca was already gathering the show's wagons. That was when Mat really knew there was no escape for him. She was going to set the hook all right. She was just biding her bloody time.

hi meɪd ʃʊɹ ɔl ðə sintʃæn steɪɾ ɪn ðɛɹ wæɡənz ðət naɪt, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu. noʊbɑdi hæd sin ɛni sʌldəm əɹ deɪmeɪn ðət mæt nu, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju fəɹ wʌns.

He made sure all the Seanchan stayed in their wagons that night, and the Aes Sedai, too. Nobody had seen any sul'dam or damane that Mat knew, but the Aes Sedai did not argue for once.

tuɑn dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju, iðɝ. ʃi meɪɾ ə dɪmæn ðət sɛn sɛɾəlz aɪbɹaʊz ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ hɛɹlaɪn. ɪt wɑz fɹeɪzd əz ə ɹɪkwɛst, ɪn ə weɪ, ə ɹimaɪndɝ ʌv ə pɹɑməs i hæd meɪd, bʌɾ i nu ə dɪmænd wən ə wʊmən meɪd wʌn. wɛl, ə mæn hæd tə tʃɹʌs ðə wʊmən i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɛɹi. hi toʊld əɹ i hæd tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, dʒʌst soʊ ʃi wəd nɑt stɑɹɾ ɪmædʒənɪŋ ʃi kəɾ əv ɛniθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəɾ aʊɾ ə hɪm. hi θɔɾ ɑn ɪɾ ɔl ðə deɪ ðət lukə pʊɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊ, θɪŋkɪŋ ən swɛɾɪŋ waɪl əz mɛni sintʃæn əz nɑt keɪm tə ɡeɪp ət ðə pɝfɔɹmɝz. hi θɔɾ ɑn ɪt waɪl ðə wæɡənz waʊn istwɝd θɹu ðə hɪlz, muvɪŋ sloʊɝ ðən ɛvɝ, bʌɾ i nu wʌɾ ænsɝ i hæd tə ɡɪv.

Tuon did not argue, either. She made a demand that sent Setalle's eyebrows almost to her hairline. It was phrased as a request, in a way, a reminder of a promise he had made, but he knew a demand when a woman made one. Well, a man had to trust the woman he was going to marry. He told her he had to think on it, just so she would not start imagining she could have anything she wanted out of him. He thought on it all the day that Luca put on his show, thinking and sweating while as many Seanchan as not came to gape at the performers. He thought on it while the wagons wound eastward through the hills, moving slower than ever, but he knew what answer he had to give.

ɑn ðə θɝd deɪ æftɝ livɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə sɔl taʊn ə dʒʊɹədɔɹ, ən i toʊl tuɑn ðəɾ i wʊd. ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, ən ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd stɑp dɛd. hi wəɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. ʃi smaɪld, ən ðən ðə daɪs stɑpt. ə mæn kəd wip!

On the third day after leaving the river, they reached the salt town of Jurador, and he told Tuon that he would. She smiled at him, and the dice in his head stopped dead. He would always remember that. She smiled, and then the dice stopped. A man could weep!


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

sʌmθɪŋ flɪkɝz


Something Flickers

ðɪs də bi mædnəs," doʊmən ɹʌmbəl fɹəm wɛɹ i stʊd wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əz ɪf blɑkɪŋ ðə weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡən. meɪbi hi wɑz. hɪz dʒɔ wɑz θɹʌs fɔɹwɝd bɛlɪdʒɝənli, stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə bɪɹd ðət wɑz tʃɹɪmd ʃɔɹt bʌt stɪl lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd, ən i wɑz wɝkɪŋ ɪz hænz laɪk ə mæn θɪŋkɪŋ ə meɪkɪŋ fɪsts, əɹ ɡɹæplɪŋ wɪð sʌmθɪŋ. ə waɪd mæn, doʊmən, ən nɑɾ əz fæɾ əz i lʊkt ɑn fɝst ɡlæns. mæt wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd fɪsts əɹ ɡɹæplɪŋ, ɪf i kʊd. hi fɪnɪʃt taɪɪŋ ðə blæk sɪlk skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, haɪɾɪŋ ɪz skɑɹ, ən tʌk ðə lɔŋ ɛnz ɪndə hɪz koʊt. ðə tʃæns ðət ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwʌn ɪn dʒʊɹədɔɹ u nu əbaʊɾ ə mæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ ə blæk skɑɹf. . , . wɛl, ði ɑdz simd ɡʊɾ ivən dɪskaʊntɪŋ ɪz lʌk. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪz biɪŋ tɑvɝən tə bi fæktɝɾ ɪn, bʌɾ ɪf ðət wɑz gɑnə bɹɪŋ ɪm feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð sjuɹɔθ əɹ ə fɪsfəl ə sɝvəns fɹəm ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, hi kəd steɪ ɪn bɛd wɪð ə blæŋkət ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, ən ɪt stɪl wəd hæpən.

This do be madness," Domon rumbled from where he stood with his arms folded as if blocking the way out of the wagon. Maybe he was. His jaw was thrust forward belligerently, sticking out a beard that was trimmed short but still longer than the hair on his head, and he was working his hands like a man thinking of making fists, or grappling with something. A wide man, Domon, and not as fat as he looked on first glance. Mat wanted to avoid fists or grappling, if he could. He finished tying the black silk scarf around his neck, hiding his scar, and tucked the long ends into his coat. The chance that there was anyone in Jurador who knew about a man in Ebou Dar wearing a black scarf. . , . Well, the odds seemed good even discounting his luck. Of course, there was always his being ta'veren to be factored in, but if that was going to bring him face-to-face with Suroth or a fistful of servants from the Tarasin Palace, he could stay in bed with a blanket wrapped around his head, and it still would happen.

səmtaɪmz, jə dʒʌs hæd tə tʃɹʌs tə lʌk. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, wən i woʊk ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ðə daɪs hæɾ əɡɛn bɪn tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðeɪ wɝ baʊnsɪŋ ɔf ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz skʌl stɪl. "aɪ pɹɑməst," hi sɛd. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi bæk ɪn disən kloʊðz.

Sometimes, you just had to trust to luck. The trouble was, when he woke this morning, the dice had again been tumbling in his head. They were bouncing off the inside of his skull still. "I promised," he said. It was good to be back in decent clothes.

ðə koʊt wɑz ə faɪn ɡɹin wʊl, wɛl kʌɾ ən hæŋɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz niz ən ðə tɝnd-daʊn tɑps ə hɪz buts. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi  - meɪbi ɪt kəd də wɪð ə lɪɾəl - bʌɾ i hæɾ ə tʌtʃ ə leɪs əɾ ɪz kʌfs. ən ə ɡʊd sɪlk ʃɝt. hi wɪʃt i hæɾ ə mɪɹɝ. ə mæn niɾəd tə lʊk ɪz bɛst ɑn ə deɪ laɪk ðɪs. pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz kloʊk fɹəm ðə bɛd, hi swʌŋ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. nɑɾ ə ɡɔɾi θɪŋ laɪk lukəz. dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ, nɪɹli əz dɑɹk əz naɪt. oʊnli ðə laɪnɪŋ wɑz ɹɛd. hɪz kloʊk pɪn wɑz sɪmpəl sɪlvɝ nɑts noʊ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɪz θʌmz.

The coat was a fine green wool, well cut and hanging almost to his knees and the turned-down tops of his boots. There was no embroidery  - maybe it could do with a little - but he had a touch of lace at his cuffs. And a good silk shirt. He wished he had a mirror. A man needed to look his best on a day like this. Picking up his cloak from the bed, he swung it across his shoulders. Not a gaudy thing like Luca's. Dark gray, nearly as dark as night. Only the lining was red. His cloak pin was simple silver knots no larger than his thumbs.

"ʃi ɡeɪv əɹ wɝd, beɪl," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd. "hɝ wɝd. ʃɪl nɑt bɹeɪk ðæt, ɛvɝ." ɛdʒiənɪn saʊndəɾ æbsəlutli kənvɪnst. mɔɹ kənvɪns ðən mæt wɑz, ɛniweɪ. bʌt səmtaɪmz ə mæn hæd tə teɪk ə tʃæns. ivən ɪf i wɑz weɪdʒɝɪŋ ɪz nɛk. hi hæd pɹɑməst. ən i dɪɾ əv ɪz lʌk.

"She gave her word, Bayle," Egeanin said. "Her word. She will not break that, ever." Egeanin sounded absolutely convinced. More convinced than Mat was, anyway. But sometimes a man had to take a chance. Even if he was wagering his neck. He had promised. And he did have his luck.

"ɪt stɪl bi mædnəs," doʊmən ɡɹʌmbəld. bʌɾ i muvd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ wən mæt sɛɾəld ɪz bɹɔd-bɹɪm blæk hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. wɛl, wən ɛdʒiənɪn moʊʃən ɪm əsaɪd wɪð ə kwɪk dʒɝk ə hɝ hɛd, ɛniweɪ. hi kɛpt ɪz ɡlaʊɝ, ðoʊ. ʃi fɑloʊd mæt aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡən, skaʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ən fɪdlɪŋ wɪð əɹ lɔŋ blæk wɪɡ. meɪbi ʃi stɪl fɛlt ənizi wɪð ɪt, əɹ meɪbi ɪt fɪt dɪfɹənli naʊ ðət ʃi hæd kloʊs tə ə mʌnθs ɡɹoʊθ ə hɝ oʊn hɛɹ ʌndɝniθ. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ əbaʊt bæɹhɛɾɪd jɛt, ɪn ɛni keɪs. nɑt tɪl ðəɹ wɑz ət list ənʌðɝ hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz bɪtwin əm ən ɛbu dɑɹ. meɪbi ɪt wəd nɑt bi seɪf əntɪl ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə deɪmoʊnə maʊntənz ɪndə mʊɹændi. ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ, ðə sʌn dʒʌs kɹɛstɪŋ ðə hɝaɪzən, ɪnvɪzəbəl jɛt bɪhaɪn ðə ʃoʊz kænvəs wɔl, ən ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz wɔɹm oʊnli kəmpɛɹd tə ə snoʊstɔɹm. nɑt ðə kɹɪspnəs ʌv ə leɪt-wɪntɝ mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌɾ ə tʃɪl ðət sloʊli bɔɹd dip ən pʊɾ ə feɪn mɪst ɪn jəɹ bɹɛθ. ðə ʃoʊfoʊk wɝ skɝiɪŋ əbaʊt laɪk æns ɪn ə kɪkt æntɪl, fɪlɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð ʃaʊɾəd dɪmænz tə noʊ hu hæd muv ðoʊz dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ɹɪŋz əɹ bɑɹoʊd ðət pɛɹ ə ɹɛd-spæŋɡəl bɹitʃɪz əɹ ʃɪftəd ðɪs pɝfɔɹmɪŋ plætfɔɹm. ɪt lʊkt ən saʊndəd laɪk ðə stɑɹɾ ʌv ə ɹaɪət, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil æŋɡɝ ɪn ɛni ʌv ðə vɔɪsəz. ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd ən weɪvd ɑɹmz ɔl ðə taɪm, bʌɾ ɪt nɛvɝ keɪm tə bloʊz wən ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃoʊ ɪn ði ɔfɪŋ, ən sʌmhaʊ ɛvɹi pɝfɔɹmɝ wəd bi ɪn pleɪs ən ɹɛɾi bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝs peɪtʃɹənz wɝ lɛɾ ɪn. ðeɪ maɪt bi sloʊ pækɪŋ ʌp fəɹ ðə ɹoʊd, bʌt pɝfɔɹmɪŋ mɛn mʌni, ən ðeɪ kəd muv fæst ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt.

"It still be madness," Domon grumbled. But he moved grudgingly away from the door when Mat settled his broad-brimmed black hat on his head. Well, when Egeanin motioned him aside with a quick jerk of her head, anyway. He kept his glower, though. She followed Mat out of the wagon, scowling herself and fiddling with her long black wig. Maybe she still felt uneasy with it, or maybe it fit differently now that she had close to a month's growth of her own hair underneath. Not enough to go about bareheaded yet, in any case. Not till there was at least another hundred miles between them and Ebou Dar. Maybe it would not be safe until they crossed the Damona Mountains into Murandy. The sky was clear, the sun just cresting the horizon, invisible yet behind the show's canvas wall, and the morning was warm only compared to a snowstorm. Not the crispness of a late-winter morning in the Two Rivers, but a chill that slowly bored deep and put a faint mist in your breath. The showfolk were scurrying about like ants in a kicked anthill, filling the air with shouted demands to know who had moved those juggling rings or borrowed that pair of red-spangled breeches or shifted this performing platform. It looked and sounded like the start of a riot, yet there was no real anger in any of the voices. They shouted and waved arms all the time, but it never came to blows when there was a show in the offing, and somehow every performer would be in place and ready before the first patrons were let in. They might be slow packing up for the road, but performing meant money, and they could move fast enough for that.

"ju ɹɪli də θɪŋk jə kən mɛɹi hɝ," ɛdʒiənɪn mʌɾɝd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ əɾ ɪz saɪd, kɪkɪŋ əɹ wɔɹn bɹaʊn wʊlən skɝts. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ deɪnti əbaʊɾ ɛdʒiənɪn. ʃi hæɾ ə lɔŋ stʃɹaɪd, ən ʃi kɛpt ʌp izəli. dʒɹɛs əɹ noʊ dʒɹɛs, ʃi sim tə niɾ ə sɔɹɾ ɑn əɹ hɪp. "ðɛɹz noʊ ʌðɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən fəɹ ðɪs. beɪl ɪz ɹaɪt. jə ɑɹ mæd!"

"You really do think you can marry her," Egeanin muttered, striding along at his side, kicking her worn brown woolen skirts. There was nothing dainty about Egeanin. She had a long stride, and she kept up easily. Dress or no dress, she seemed to need a sword on her hip. "There's no other explanation for this. Bayle is right. You are mad!"

mæt ɡɹɪnd. "ðə kwɛstʃən ɪz, dʌz ʃi min tə mɛɹi mi? ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst pipəl mɛɹi, səmtaɪmz." wən jə nu jə wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæŋ, ði oʊnli θɪŋ tə də wɑz ɡɹɪn ət ðə nus. soʊ hi ɡɹɪn ən lɛft əɹ stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð ə skaʊl ɑn əɹ hɑɹd feɪs. hi θɔt ʃi wɑz ɡɹoʊlɪŋ kɝsɪz ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ. ʃi wɑz nɑt ðə wʌn u hæd tə mɛɹi ðə læs pɝsən ɑn ɝθ ʃi wɑntəd tə. ə noʊbəlwʊmən, ɔl kul ɹɪzɝv ən əɹ noʊz ɪn ði ɛɹ, wən i laɪk bɑɹmeɪdz wɪð ɹɛɾi smaɪlz ən wɪlɪŋ aɪz. ði ɛɹ tə ə θɹoʊn, ən nɑt dʒʌst ɛni θɹoʊn; ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ði ɪmpɪɹiəl θɹoʊn ə sintʃæn. ə wʊmən u spʌn ɪz hɛd laɪk ə tɑp ən lɛft ɪm wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i hɛld əɹ kæptɪv əɹ ʃi hɛl hɪm. wən feɪt ɡɹɪp jə baɪ ðə θɹoʊt, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt ɡɹɪn. hi kɛpt ə dʒɔnti peɪs tɪl i wɑz ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə wɪndoʊləs pɝpəl wæɡən, ən ðən i mɪst ə stɛp. ə klʌstɝ ʌv ækɹəbæts, fɔɹ lɪmbɝ mɛn u kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃeɪvænə bɹʌðɝz ðoʊ ɪt wɑz pleɪn əz ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm dɪfɹən kʌntʃɹiz, nɑt dʒʌs dɪfɹən mʌðɝz, ɹʌʃt aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡɹin wæɡən nɪɹbaɪ, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ waɪldli ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ spɛɹɾ ə ɡlæns fəɹ ðə pɝpəl wæɡən ən ənʌðɝ fəɹ mæt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ tu ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹɡjəmənt, ən tʃɹɑɾɪŋ tu fæst, fəɹ mɔɹ. ɡɔɹɾɝən wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə pɝpəl wilz, skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə tu wɪmən u stʊɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə wæɡənz wʊɾən stɛps. tu wɪmən. boʊθ swɑðd ɪn dɑɹk kloʊks, feɪsəz kənsild, jɛt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðə flaʊɝd hɛd skɑɹf hæŋɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tɔlɝ wʊmənz kaʊl. wɛl. hi ʃʊɾə noʊ tuɑn wəd wɑn əɹ meɪɾ əlɔŋ. noʊbəlwɪmən nɛvɝ wɛn ɛniwɛɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə meɪd. bɛɾ ə pɛni əɹ bɛɾ ə kɹaʊn, ɪn ði ɛn ɪɾ ɔl keɪm daʊn tə ə tɔs ə ðə daɪs dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ðeɪ hæd hæd ðɛɹ tʃæns tə bɪtʃɹeɪ hɪm. stɪl, hi wɑz bɛɾɪŋ ɑn ə wʊmən meɪkɪŋ ðə seɪm tʃɔɪs twaɪs ɹʌnɪŋ. ɑn tu wɪmən duɪŋ ɪt. wʌt ful wəd meɪk ɑdz ɑn ðæt?

Mat grinned. "The question is, does she mean to marry me? The strangest people marry, sometimes." When you knew you were going to hang, the only thing to do was grin at the noose. So he grinned and left her standing there with a scowl on her hard face. He thought she was growling curses under her breath, though he did not understand why. She was not the one who had to marry the last person on earth she wanted to. A noblewoman, all cool reserve and her nose in the air, when he liked barmaids with ready smiles and willing eyes. The heir to a throne, and not just any throne; the Crystal Throne, the Imperial Throne of Seanchan. A woman who spun his head like a top and left him wondering whether he held her captive or she held him. When fate gripped you by the throat, there was nothing to do but grin. He kept a jaunty pace till he was in sight of the windowless purple wagon, and then he missed a step. A cluster of acrobats, four limber men who called themselves the Chavana brothers though it was plain as their noses they came from different countries, not just different mothers, rushed out of a green wagon nearby, shouting and gesturing wildly at one another. They spared a glance for the purple wagon and another for Mat, but they were too engrossed in their argument, and trotting too fast, for more. Gorderan was leaning against one of the purple wheels, scratching his head and frowning at the two women who stood at the foot of the wagon's wooden steps. Two women. Both swathed in dark cloaks, faces concealed, yet there was no mistaking the flowered head scarf hanging out of the taller woman's cowl. Well. He should have know Tuon would want her maid along. Noblewomen never went anywhere without a maid. Bet a penny or bet a crown, in the end it all came down to a toss of the dice just the same. They had had their chance to betray him. Still, he was betting on a woman making the same choice twice running. On two women doing it. What fool would make odds on that?

bʌɾ i hæd tə tɔs ðə daɪs.

But he had to toss the dice.

ɪksɛpt, ðeɪ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹoʊlɪŋ.

Except, they were already rolling.

hi mɛt sɪlutʃəz koʊl blu stɛɹ wɪð ə smaɪl ən swɛpt ɔf ɪz hæt tə meɪk ən ɛləɡən lɛɡ tə tuɑn. nɑt tu ʃoʊi, wɪð dʒʌst ə smɔl flɝɪʃ ə hɪz kloʊk. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ ʃɑpɪŋ?" hi vɛɹi nɪɹli kɔld əɹ "maɪ leɪɾi," bʌɾ əntɪl ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə seɪ hɪz neɪm. . . .

He met Selucia's cold blue stare with a smile and swept off his hat to make an elegant leg to Tuon. Not too showy, with just a small flourish of his cloak. "Are you ready to go shopping?" He very nearly called her "my Lady," but until she was willing to say his name. . . .

"aɪ hæv bɪn ɹɛɾi fəɹ ən aʊɝ, tɔɪ," tuɑn dʒɹɔl kuli. kæʒəwəli lɪftɪŋ ən ɛdʒ ə hɪz kloʊk, ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə ɹɛd sɪlk laɪnɪŋ ən aɪɾ ɪz koʊt bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ ðə kloʊk fɔl. "leɪs suts ju. pɝhæps əl əv leɪs æɾəd tə jəɹ ɹoʊbz ɪf aɪ meɪk jə ə kʌbɛɹɝ." hɪz smaɪl slɪp fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. kəd ʃi stɪl meɪk ɪm dɑ'-koʊvæl ɪf ʃi mɛɹid hɪm? hi wəɾ əv tə æsk ɛdʒiənɪn. laɪt, waɪ dɪd wɪmən nɛvɝ meɪk ɪɾ izi?

"I have been ready for an hour, Toy," Tuon drawled coolly. Casually lifting an edge of his cloak, she glanced at the red silk lining and eyed his coat before letting the cloak fall. "Lace suits you.
