Perhaps I will have lace added to your robes if I make you a cupbearer." His smile slipped for an instant. Could she still make him da'-covale if she married him? He would have to ask Egeanin. Light, why did women never make it easy?

"du jə wɑn mi tə kʌm əlɔŋ, maɪ lɔɹd?" ɡɔɹɾɝən æsk sloʊli, nɑt kwaɪt lʊkɪŋ ət ðə wɪmən naʊ. hi tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt ən dɪd nɑt kwaɪt lʊk ət mæt, iðɝ. "dʒʌs tə kæɹi, meɪbi?"

"Do you want me to come along, my Lord?" Gorderan asked slowly, not quite looking at the women now. He tucked his thumbs behind his belt and did not quite look at Mat, either. "Just to carry, maybe?"

tuɑn dɪd nɑt seɪ ə wɝd. ʃi dʒʌst stʊd ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət mæt, weɪɾɪŋ, bɪɡ aɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ kulɝ baɪ ðə sɛkənd. ðə daɪs baʊnst ən ɹæɾəld ɪn ɪz hɛd. wɛl, hi oʊnli hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə hɑɹtbit bɪfɔɹ dʒɝkɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə sɛn ðə ɹɛdɑɹm əweɪ. meɪbi tu hɑɹtbits. hi hæd tə tʃɹʌst ɪz lʌk. tʃɹʌst əɹ wɝd. tʃɹʌst ɪz ðə saʊn ə dɛθ. hi stɛpt ɑn ðət θɔt hɑɹd. ðɪs wɑz noʊ sɔŋ, ən noʊ oʊl mɛmɹi kəd ɡaɪd hɪm. ðə daɪs ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl kɛp spɪnɪŋ.

Tuon did not say a word. She just stood there looking up at Mat, waiting, big eyes getting cooler by the second. The dice bounced and rattled in his head. Well, he only hesitated a heartbeat before jerking his head to send the Redarm away. Maybe two heartbeats. He had to trust his luck. Trust her word. Trust is the sound of death. He stepped on that thought hard. This was no song, and no old memory could guide him. The dice inside his skull kept spinning.

wɪð ə slaɪt baʊ, hi ɔfɝɾ ɪz ɑɹm, wɪtʃ tuɑn ɪɡzæmən əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin ən ɑɹm bɪfɔɹ, pɝsɪŋ ðoʊz fʊl lɪps. ðən ʃi ɡæðɝɾ əɹ kloʊk ən sɛɾ ɔf wɪð sɪlutʃə ɡlaɪɾɪŋ əɾ əɹ hilz, livɪŋ ɪm tə hɝi æftɝ ðɛm. noʊ, wɪmən nɛvɝ dɪd meɪk ɪɾ izi.

With a slight bow, he offered his arm, which Tuon examined as if she had never seen an arm before, pursing those full lips. Then she gathered her cloak and set off with Selucia gliding at her heels, leaving him to hurry after them. No, women never did make it easy.

dɪspaɪt ði ɝli aʊɝ, tu bɝli fɛloʊz wɪð kʌdʒəlz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ði ɛntʃɹəns, ən ə θɝd wɪð ə klɪɹ ɡlæs pɪtʃɝ tə teɪk ðə kɔɪnz ən dʌmp əm θɹu ə slɑɾ ɪn ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæp bɑks ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. itʃ ə ðə θɹi lʊk tu klʌmzi tə pɑm ə kɑpɝ wɪθaʊt fɔlɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs, bʌt lukə tʊk noʊ tʃænsəz. twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi pipəl wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə hɛvi ɹoʊps ðət lɛd tə ðə bɪɡ blu bænɝ neɪmɪŋ lukəs ʃoʊ, ən ənfɔɹtʃənətli, lətɛl wɑz ðɛɹ, tu, stɝn-feɪst ɪn ə dʒɹɛs soʊn wɪð kɹɪmzən spæŋɡəlz ən ə kloʊk soʊn wɪð blu. lukəs waɪf tʃɹeɪn bɛɹz. mæt θɔt ðə bɛɹz dɪd ðɛɹ tʃɹɪks fəɹ fɪɹ ʃi maɪt baɪt ðɛm. "aɪ hæv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn hænd," hi toʊl hɝ. "bɪliv mi, ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt." hi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv spɛɹɾ ɪz bɹɛθ. lətɛl ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ wɝidli ət tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə. ʃi ən əɹ hʌzbənd wɝ ði oʊnli tu ʃoʊfoʊk u nu hu ðeɪ wɝ. ðəɹ hæd sim noʊ ɹizən tə tɛl iðɝ əbaʊt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋz dʒɔnt. lukə, ət list, wʊɾə hæd kɪɾənz. ðə stɛɹ lətɛl ʃɪftəd tə mæt wɑz nɑt wɝid, dʒʌst stoʊn hɑɹd. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli, "ɪf jə sɛn əs tə ðə ɡæloʊz, jə sɛn jɝsɛlf." ðən ʃi snɪft ən wɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə pipəl weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn. lətɛl wɑz ivən bɛɾɝ ðən lukə ət dʒʌdʒɪŋ ðə weɪɾ ʌv ə pɝs bɪfɔɹ ðə dʒɹɔstʃɹɪŋz wɝ əndʌn. ʃi wɑz ɔlsoʊ tɛn taɪmz tʌfɝ ðən əɹ hʌzbənd. ðə daɪs tʌmbəld ɑn.

Despite the early hour, two burly fellows with cudgels were already guarding the entrance, and a third with a clear glass pitcher to take the coins and dump them through a slot in the iron-strapped box on the ground. Each of the three looked too clumsy to palm a copper without falling on his face, but Luca took no chances. Twenty or thirty people were already waiting inside the heavy ropes that led to the big blue banner naming Lucas show, and unfortunately, Latelle was there, too, stern-faced in a dress sewn with crimson spangles and a cloak sewn with blue. Lucas wife trained bears. Mat thought the bears did their tricks for fear she might bite them. "I have everything in hand," he told her. "Believe me, there's nothing to worry about." He might as well have spared his breath. Latelle ignored him, frowning worriedly at Tuon and Selucia. She and her husband were the only two showfolk who knew who they were. There had seemed no reason to tell either about this morning's jaunt. Luca, at least, would have had kittens. The stare Latelle shifted to Mat was not worried, just stone hard. "Remember," she said quietly, "if you send us to the gallows, you send yourself." Then she sniffed and went back to studying the people waiting to get in. Latelle was even better than Luca at judging the weight of a purse before the drawstrings were undone. She was also ten times tougher than her husband. The dice tumbled on.

wʌtɛvɝ hæd sɛɾ əm spɪnɪŋ, hi hæd nɑt jɛt ɹitʃt ðə feɪtfəl pɔɪnt. ðə dəsaɪɾɪŋ pɔɪnt.

Whatever had set them spinning, he had not yet reached the fateful point. The deciding point.

"ʃi ɪz ə ɡʊd waɪf fəɹ mæstɝ lukə," tuɑn mɝmɝd wən ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn ə lɪɾəl weɪ.

"She is a good wife for Master Luca," Tuon murmured when they had gone a little way.

mæt lʊkt əɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, ən ɹisɛɾəld ɪz hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ mɑkɝi ɪn əɹ toʊn. dɪd ʃi heɪt lukə ðət mʌtʃ? əɹ wɑz ʃi seɪɪŋ wʌt sɔɹɾ ʌv waɪf ʃi wəd bi? əɹ . . . ? bɝn hɪm, hi kəd ɡoʊ əz kɹeɪzi əz doʊmən θɔɾ i wɑz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʌzəl ðɪs wʊmən aʊt. ʃi hæd tə bi ðə ɹizən fəɹ ðə fil ə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd. wʌt wɑz ʃi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?

Mat looked at her sideways, and resettled his hat on his head. There had been no mockery in her tone. Did she hate Luca that much? Or was she saying what sort of wife she would be? Or . . . ? Burn him, he could go as crazy as Domon thought he was, trying to puzzle this woman out. She had to be the reason for the feel of dice in his head. What was she going to do?

ɪt wɑz ə ʃɔɹt wɔk əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn tə ðə taʊn, əlɔŋ ə hɑɹd-pækt ɹoʊd θɹu hɪlz ðət wɝ tʃɹiləs hɪɹ, bʌt pipəl dɑɾəd ðə ɹoʊd ðə weɪ wɪndmɪlz ən sɔl pænz dɑɾəd ðə hɪlz.

It was a short walk away from the rising sun to the town, along a hard-packed road through hills that were treeless here, but people dotted the road the way windmills and salt pans dotted the hills.

stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ðeɪ muv soʊ pɝpəsfəli ðeɪ sim nɑt tə si ɛniwʌn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. mæt dɑdʒd ə ɹaʊndfeɪs mæn u nɪɹli wɔkt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə hɪm, wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɪm əv tə dʒʌmp əweɪ fɹəm ə waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl fɛloʊ meɪkɪŋ ə ɡʊd spiɾ ɑn spɪnli lɛɡz. ðət pʊɾ ɪm ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə plʌmp ɡɝl u wʊɾə ɹʌn ʌp ðə fɹʌn ə hɪm ɪf i hæd nɑt dʒʌmpt əɡɛn.

Staring straight ahead, they moved so purposefully they seemed not to see anyone in front of them. Mat dodged a roundfaced man who nearly walked right into him, which made him have to jump away from a white-haired old fellow making a good speed on spindly legs. That put him in front of a plump girl who would have run up the front of him if he had not jumped again.

"ɑɹ jə pɹæktəsɪŋ ə dæns, tɔɪ?" tuɑn sɛd, piɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm oʊvɝ ə slɪm ʃoʊldɝ. hɝ bɹɛθ meɪɾ ə feɪnt waɪt mɪst ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ kaʊl. "ɪɾ ɪzən vɛɹi ɡɹeɪsfəl." hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, dʒʌs tə pɔɪn aʊt haʊ kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹoʊd wɑz, ən sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪzd i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ si ɛniwʌn bɪɑn əɹ ən sɪlutʃə. ðə pipəl u hæd bɪn ðəɹ wɝ dʒʌst ɡɔn, ðə ɹoʊɾ ɛmpti əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si bɪfɔɹ ɪt meɪɾ ə bɛnd. sloʊli, hi tɝn ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə ʃoʊ, iðɝ, dʒʌs ðə foʊk weɪɾɪŋ ɪn laɪn, ən ðət lʊk noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ.

"Are you practicing a dance, Toy?" Tuon said, peering up at him over a slim shoulder. Her breath made a faint white mist in front of her cowl. "It isn't very graceful." He opened his mouth, just to point out how crowded the road was, and suddenly he realized he could no longer see anyone beyond her and Selucia. The people who had been there were just gone, the road empty as far as he could see before it made a bend. Slowly, he turned his head. There was no one between him and the show, either, just the folk waiting in line, and that looked no longer than before.

bɪɑn ðə ʃoʊ, ðə ɹoʊd waʊn ɪndə ðə hɪlz təwɔɹɾ ə dɪstən fɔɹəst, ɛmpti. nɑɾ ə soʊl ɪn saɪt. hi pɹɛs fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst, filɪŋ ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən θɹu hɪz koʊt. dʒʌst ə pis ə sɪlvɝ ɑn ə ɹɔhaɪd kɔɹd. hi wɪʃt ɪt fɛl koʊld əz aɪs. tuɑn ɑɹtʃt ən aɪbɹaʊ. sɪlutʃəz stɛɹ neɪmd ɪm ful.

Beyond the show, the road wound into the hills toward a distant forest, empty. Not a soul in sight. He pressed fingers against his chest, feeling the foxhead medallion through his coat. Just a piece of silver on a rawhide cord. He wished it felt cold as ice. Tuon arched an eyebrow. Selucia's stare named him fool.

"aɪ kæn baɪ jə ə dʒɹɛs stændɪŋ hɪɹ," hi sɛd. ðət wɑz ðə pɔɪn ə ðɪs ɛkspədɪʃən, hɪz pɹɑməs tə faɪn tuɑn sʌmθɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən dʒɹɛsəz ðət hʌŋ ɑn əɹ ən meɪɾ əɹ lʊk ə tʃaɪld ɪn ə ɡɹoʊnʌps kloʊðɪŋ. ət list, hi wɑz pɹɪɾi ʃʊɹ i hæd pɹɑməs ðæt, ən ʃi wɑz pɝfəkli sɝɾən. ðə niɾəlwɝk ə ðə ʃoʊz simstʃɹəsəz mɛt wɪð tuɑnz əpɹuvəl, bʌt nɑt ðə klɔθ ðeɪ hæɾ əveɪləbəl.

"I can't buy you a dress standing here," he said. That was the point of this expedition, his promise to find Tuon something better than dresses that hung on her and made her look a child in a grownup's clothing. At least, he was pretty sure he had promised that, and she was perfectly certain. The needlework of the show's seamstresses met with Tuon's approval, but not the cloth they had available.

pɝfɔɹmɝz' kɑstumz ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð spæŋɡəlz ən bidz ən bɹaɪt kʌlɝz, bʌt ðə klɔθ wɑz juʒəwəli wʌtɛvɝ kəd bi faʊn tʃipli. ðoʊz u hæd bɛɾɝ kɛpt ɪɾ ən juzd ɪt tɪl ɪt wɔɹ aʊt. dʒʊɹədɔɹ meɪɾ ɪts mʌni fɹəm sɔlt, ðoʊ, ən sɔl meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə mʌni. ðə taʊnz ʃɑps ʃəɾ ɔfɝ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə mətɪɹiəl ə wʊmən kəd wɪʃ.

Performers' costumes glittered with spangles and beads and bright colors, but the cloth was usually whatever could be found cheaply. Those who had better kept it and used it till it wore out. Jurador made its money from salt, though, and salt made a great deal of money. The town's shops should offer any sort of material a woman could wish.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɪŋɡɝ-wɪɡəlɪŋ, ðɪs taɪm. tuɑn ʃɛɹɾ ə lʊk wɪð sɪlutʃə. ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ə ɹaɪ, ɹufəl twɪs tə hɝ maʊθ. tuɑn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ən ðeɪ ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ kloʊks ən stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə taʊnz aɪɝn-stʌɾɪd ɡeɪts. wɪmən! hi hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp əɡɛn. ðeɪ wɝ ɪz pɹɪznɝz, æftɝ ɔl. ðeɪ wɝ. ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt lɔŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm. hæɾ ɛni ʌv ðoʊz pipəl kæst ʃædoʊz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ vænɪʃt? hi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ɛni ʌv əm bɹiðɪŋ ə mɪst, iðɝ. ɪt hɑɹdli sim tə mæɾɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, ən i wɑz nɑt gɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd kʌm fɹəm əɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn. pɹɑbli sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð biɪŋ tɑvɝən. hi wɑz gɑnə pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. hi wɑz. ðə daɪs ɹætlɪŋ əweɪ lɛft ɹum fəɹ nʌθɪŋ ɛls. ðə ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz simd ɪnkjʊɹiəs əbaʊt stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, əɹ ət list əbaʊɾ ə mæn ən tu wɪmən əfʊt. hɑɹd-feɪs fɛloʊz ɪn waɪtpəntɪd bɹɛstpleɪts ən kɑnɪkəl hɛlməts wɪð wʌt lʊk laɪk hɔɹsteɪlz fəɹ kɹɛsts, ðeɪ ɹæn ɪmpæsɪv aɪz oʊvɝ ðə kloʊkt wɪmən, lɪŋɡɝɪŋ səspɪʃəsli ə moʊmən ɑn mæt fəɹ səm ɹizən, ən ðən ɹɪtɝn tə linɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hælbɝdz ən stɛɹɪŋ blæŋkli ət ðə ɹoʊd. ðeɪ wɝ loʊkəl mɛn, moʊs laɪkli, ɪn ɛni keɪs nɑt sintʃæn. ðə sɔl mɝtʃəns ən ðə loʊkəl leɪɾi, æɛθɪleɪn, hu əpɛɹənli sɛd wʌtɛvɝ ðə sɔl mɝtʃəns toʊld əɹ tə, hæd swɔɹn ði oʊðz ə ɹɪtɝn wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən ən ɔfɝd tə peɪ ə sɔl tæks bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ æskt. noʊ daʊt ðə sintʃæn wəd ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn tə ɪnstɔlɪŋ səm sɔɹɾ ʌv əfɪʃəl hɪɹ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, dʒʌs tə kip ən aɪ ɑn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ðeɪ hæd mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt jusəz fəɹ ðɛɹ soʊlʒɝz. mæt hæd sɛn tɑm ən dʒulɪn boʊθ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sintʃæn ɪn dʒʊɹədɔɹ bɪfɔɹ əɡɹiɪŋ tə ðɪs ɪkskɝʒən. ə ful kəd tʃɹɪp oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn lʌk ɪf i wɑz nɑt kɛɹfəl. ɪt wɑz ə pɹɑspɝəs, bɪzi taʊn, dʒʊɹədɔɹ, wɪð stoʊn-peɪv stʃɹits, moʊst ə ðɛm waɪɾ ən ɔl laɪnd wɪð stoʊn bɪldɪŋz ɹuft ɪn ɹɛɾɪʃ taɪlz. haʊsəz ən ɪnz ɹʌbd ʃoʊldɝz wɪð steɪbəlz ən tævɝnz, ɪn ə nɔɪzi dʒʌmbəl wɪð ə blæksmɪθs klæŋɪŋ hæmɝ ɑn ən ænvəl hɪɹ ən ðə ɹækəɾɪŋ ʌv ə ɹʌɡwivɝz lumz ðɛɹ, ən ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɪt simd, kupɝz hæmɝɪŋ bænz ɑn taɪt bæɹəlz fəɹ tʃɹænspɔɹɾɪŋ sɔlt. hɔkɝz kɹaɪd pɪnz ən ɹɪbənz, mit paɪz ən ɹoʊstəd nʌts fɹəm tʃɹeɪz, əɹ wɪntɝ-ɹɪŋkəl tɝnəps ən sɑɹi plʌmz fɹəm bæɹoʊz. ɑn ɛvɹi stʃɹit mɛn ən wɪmən stʊd ɡɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə dɪspleɪ ɡʊdz ɑn nɛɹoʊ teɪbəlz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ ʃɑps ən bɛloʊd lɪsts ʌv wʌt wɑz ɔfɝd wɪðɪn. pɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə sɔl mɝtʃəns' haʊsəz wɑz izi, ðoʊ, θɹi stɔɹiz ə stoʊn ɹæðɝ ðən tu, kʌvɝɪŋ eɪt taɪmz əz mʌtʃ ɡɹaʊn əz ɛni ʌðɝz, itʃ wɪð ə kɑləmd wɔk oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ən ʃildɪd baɪ waɪt ɹɔt-aɪɝn skɹinz bɪtwin ðə kɑləmz. ðə loʊɝ wɪndoʊz ɑn moʊs haʊsəz hæd ðoʊz skɹinz, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɔlweɪz peɪntəd. ðət mʌtʃ wɑz ɹɛmənɪsən ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt lɪɾəl ɛls wɑz, bɪɑn ði ɑləv kəmpliksənz ə ðə pipəl. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ dip nɛklinz ɪkspoʊzɪŋ klivədʒ hɪɹ, noʊ skɝts soʊn ʌp tə dɪspleɪ kʌlɝd pɛɾikoʊts. ðə wɪmən wɔɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd dʒɹɛsəz wɪð haɪ nɛks ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðɛɹ tʃɪnz, ə lɪɾəl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi fəɹ ðə kɑmən foʊk, ə ɡɹeɪt dil fəɹ ðə ɹɪtʃɝ, hu wɔɹ kloʊks ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd tɑp tə bɑɾəm ən ʃɪɹ veɪlz hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ feɪsəz fɹəm koʊmz ʌv ɡoʊld-wɝk əɹ kɑɹvd aɪvɝi stʌk ɪndə dɑɹk, kɔɪl bɹeɪdz. ðə mɛnz ʃɔɹt koʊts wɝ wɝkt ɔlmoʊst əz θɪkli, ɪn kʌlɝz dʒʌst əz bɹaɪt, ən ɹɪtʃ əɹ pʊɹ, moʊs mɛn wɔɹ ə lɔŋ bɛl naɪf wɪð ə bleɪɾ ə lɪɾəl lɛs kɝv ðən ðoʊz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ.

There was no finger-wiggling, this time. Tuon shared a look with Selucia. The taller woman shook her head, a wry, rueful twist to her mouth. Tuon shook her head. And they gathered their cloaks and started toward the town's iron-studded gates. Women! He hurried to catch up again. They were his prisoners, after all. They were. Their shadows stretched out long in front of them. Had any of those people cast shadows before they vanished? He could not recall any of them breathing a mist, either. It hardly seemed to matter. They were gone, and he was not going to think about where they had come from or where they had gone. Probably something to do with being ta'veren. He was going to put it out of his head. He was. The dice rattling away left room for nothing else. The gate guards seemed incurious about strangers, or at least about a man and two women afoot. Hard-faced fellows in whitepainted breastplates and conical helmets with what looked like horsetails for crests, they ran impassive eyes over the cloaked women, lingering suspiciously a moment on Mat for some reason, and then returned to leaning on their halberds and staring blankly at the road. They were local men, most likely, in any case not Seanchan. The salt merchants and the local lady, Aethelaine, who apparently said whatever the salt merchants told her to, had sworn the Oaths of Return without hesitation and offered to pay a salt tax before they were asked. No doubt the Seanchan would get around to installing some sort of official here eventually, just to keep an eye on everything, but for the moment, they had more important uses for their soldiers. Mat had sent Thom and Juilin both to make sure there were no Seanchan in Jurador before agreeing to this excursion. A fool could trip over his own luck if he was not careful. It was a prosperous, busy town, Jurador, with stone-paved streets, most of them wide and all lined with stone buildings roofed in reddish tiles. Houses and inns rubbed shoulders with stables and taverns, in a noisy jumble with a blacksmith's clanging hammer on an anvil here and the racketing of a rugweaver's looms there, and everywhere, it seemed, coopers hammering bands on tight barrels for transporting salt. Hawkers cried pins and ribbons, meat pies and roasted nuts from trays, or winter-wrinkled turnips and sorry plums from barrows. On every street men and women stood guard over the display goods on narrow tables in front of their shops and bellowed lists of what was offered within. Picking out the salt merchants' houses was easy, though, three stories of stone rather than two, covering eight times as much ground as any others, each with a columned walk overlooking the street and shielded by white wrought-iron screens between the columns. The lower windows on most houses had those screens, though not always painted. That much was reminiscent of Ebou Dar, but little else was, beyond the olive complexions of the people. There were no deep necklines exposing cleavage here, no skirts sewn up to display colored petticoats. The women wore embroidered dresses with high necks right up to their chins, a little embroidery for the common folk, a great deal for the richer, who wore cloaks embroidered top to bottom and sheer veils hanging over their faces from combs of gold-work or carved ivory stuck into dark, coiled braids. The men's short coats were worked almost as thickly, in colors just as bright, and rich or poor, most men wore a long belt knife with a blade a little less curved than those in Ebou Dar.

ɹɪtʃ əɹ pʊɹ, ðə fɛloʊz dɪɾ əv ə tɛndənsi tə fɑndəl ðɛɹ naɪf hɪls əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ə faɪt, soʊ meɪbi ðət wɑz ðə seɪm.

Rich or poor, the fellows did have a tendency to fondle their knife hilts as if expecting a fight, so maybe that was the same.

ðə leɪɾi æɛθɪleɪnz pæləs əpɪɹd noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪd ðən ðə sɔl mɝtʃəns'

The Lady Aethelaine's palace appeared no different from the outside than the salt merchants'

mæntʃənz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd ɑn ðə taʊnz meɪn skwɛɹ, ə waɪɾ ɪkspæns ə pɑlɪʃt stoʊn wɛɹ ə bɹɔd ɹaʊn mɑɹbəl faʊntən spɹeɪd wɔɾɝ ɪndə ði ɛɹ. pipəl fɪl ðɛɹ bʌkəts ən bɪɡ pɑɾɝi wɔɾɝ dʒɑɹz fɹəm paɪps spɪlɪŋ ɪndə stoʊn beɪsənz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ʌv ʌðɝ skwɛɹz, ðoʊ. ðə bɪɡ faʊntən pʊɾ aʊɾ ə smɛl ə bɹaɪn. ɪt wɑz ə sɪmbəl ə dʒʊɹədɔɹz wɛlθ, pʌmp fɹəm ðə seɪm sɔɹs əz ðə sɔlt wɛlz ɪn ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪlz. mæt ɡɑt tə si ə ɡʊd dil ə ðə taʊn bɪfɔɹ ðə sʌn klaɪmd ivən hæfweɪ tə ɪts nun pik. ɛvɹi taɪm tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə spɑɾəd ə ʃɑp wɪð sɪlks dɪspleɪɾ aʊt fɹʌnt, ðeɪ stɑpt ət ðə lɔŋ nɛɹoʊ teɪbəl tə fil boʊls ə klɔθ ən wɪspɝ wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, weɪvɪŋ ɔf ði ətɛnʃənz ə ðə wɑtʃfəl ʃɑpkipɝ. ðoʊz kɛpt ə vɛɹi wɑtʃfəl aɪ, əntɪl ðeɪ ɹilaɪz mæt wɑz wɪð ðə tu wɪmən. ɪn ðɛɹ staʊt wʊlənz, wɛl wɔɹn ən bædli fɪɾɪŋ, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt lʊk kʌstəmɝz fəɹ sɪlk.

mansions, but it was located on the town's main square, a wide expanse of polished stone where a broad round marble fountain sprayed water into the air. People filled their buckets and big pottery water jars from pipes spilling into stone basins at the corners of other squares, though. The big fountain put out a smell of brine. It was a symbol of Jurador's wealth, pumped from the same source as the salt wells in the surrounding hills. Mat got to see a good deal of the town before the sun climbed even halfway to its noon peak. Every time Tuon and Selucia spotted a shop with silks displayed out front, they stopped at the long narrow table to feel bolts of cloth and whisper with their heads together, waving off the attentions of the watchful shopkeeper. Those kept a very watchful eye, until they realized Mat was with the two women. In their stout woolens, well worn and badly fitting, they did not look customers for silk.

mæt, wɪð wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪz kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk tə ɪkspoʊz ðə laɪnɪŋ, dɪd. wɛnɛvɝ i tʃɹaɪd tə ʃoʊ ən ɪntʃɹəst, ðoʊ - wɪmən sɛd ðeɪ wɑntəd jə tə ʃoʊ ən ɪntʃɹəst! - wɛnɛvɝ i ɡɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ seɪɪŋ, ðə wɪmən fɛl saɪlən ən lʊkt ət hɪm, kul dɑɹk aɪz ən kul blu stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ dip kaʊlz, əntɪl i fɛl bæk ə stɛp əɹ tu. ðən sɪlutʃə wəd bɛn əɹ hɛd tə tuɑnz, ən ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ bæk tə mɝmɝɪŋ ən fɪŋɡɝɪŋ sɪlk, ɹɛd sɪlk, blu sɪlk, ɡɹin sɪlk, smuð ʃɪmɝɪŋ sɪlk ən bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlk. dʒʊɹədɔɹ wɑz ə vɛɹi wɛlθi taʊn. lʌkəli, hi hæd tʌkt ə fæt pɝs ʌv ɡoʊld ɪndə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. nʌn ʌv ɪt sim tə bi ɹaɪt, ðoʊ. ɪnɛvəɾəbli, tuɑn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm ɡlaɪɾɪd əweɪ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd wɪð mæt hɝiɪŋ tə kip ʌp əz fɑɹ əz ðə nɛkst ʃɑp ʃoʊɪŋ sɪlks. ðə daɪs kəntɪnjud tə baʊns ɔf ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɪz skʌl.

Mat, with one side of his cloak thrown back to expose the lining, did. Whenever he tried to show an interest, though - women said they wanted you to show an interest! - whenever he got close enough to hear what they were saying, the women fell silent and looked at him, cool dark eyes and cool blue staring out of their deep cowls, until he fell back a step or two. Then Selucia would bend her head to Tuon's, and they would go back to murmuring and fingering silk, red silk, blue silk, green silk, smooth shimmering silk and brocaded silk. Jurador was a very wealthy town. Luckily, he had tucked a fat purse of gold into his coat pocket. None of it seemed to be right, though. Inevitably, Tuon shook her head, and the pair of them glided away into the crowd with Mat hurrying to keep up as far as the next shop showing silks. The dice continued to bounce off the inside of his skull.

ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz fɹəm ðə ʃoʊ hu hæd kʌm ɪndə ðə taʊn. hi spɑɾəd ɑlʌdʒɹə, hɝ feɪs fɹeɪm baɪ biɾɪd bɹeɪdz, wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn u hæd tə bi ə sɔl mɝtʃən fɹəm ði əmaʊn ə bɹaɪɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz sɪlk koʊɾ ɪn flaʊɝz ən hʌmɪŋbɝdz.

They were not the only ones from the show who had come into the town. He spotted Aludra, her face framed by beaded braids, walking through the crowd with a gray-haired man who had to be a salt merchant from the amount of bright embroidery covering his silk coat in flowers and hummingbirds.

wʌt wəd ði ɪluməneɪɾɝ wɑnt wɪð ə sɔl mɝtʃənt? wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ tə hɪm, hɪz pliz smaɪl hæɾ æɾəd ə fju kɹisɪz tə hɪz feɪs, ən i wɑz nɑɾɪŋ.

What would the Illuminator want with a salt merchant? Whatever she was saying to him, his pleased smile had added a few creases to his face, and he was nodding.

tuɑn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən ðə tu wɪmən ɡlaɪɾɪd təwɔɹd ðə nɛkst ʃɑp, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ʃɑpkipɝz dip baʊz. wɛl, moʊst ə ðoʊz wɝ dɝɛktəɾ ət mæt. meɪbi ðə skɪni ful θɔɾ i wɑntəd tə baɪ sɪlk fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. nɑt ðəɾ i wʊɾə pæst ʌp ə nu sɪlk koʊɾ əɹ θɹi, bʌɾ u kəd θɪŋk əbaʊt koʊts wən i wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs tə stɑp? dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ɑn ðə slivz ən ʃoʊldɝz.

Tuon shook her head, and the two women glided toward the next shop, ignoring the shopkeeper's deep bows. Well, most of those were directed at Mat. Maybe the skinny fool thought he wanted to buy silk for himself. Not that he would have passed up a new silk coat or three, but who could think about coats when he was waiting for those bloody dice to stop? Just a little embroidery, on the sleeves and shoulders.

tɑm wɛn baɪ klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪm, nʌklɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz ən jɔnɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd spɛn ðə naɪɾ əweɪk. hi maɪt hæv. ðə ɡlimən hæd nɑt teɪkən tə dʒɹɪŋk əɡɛn, bʌt ləpɪn ən nɹɪm kəmpleɪn əbaʊɾ ɪm ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əweɪk tɪl ɔl aʊɝz, bɝnɪŋ ə læmp soʊ hi kəd ɹiɾ ən ɹeɪ-ɹɛɾ ɪz pɹɛʃəs lɛɾɝ. wʌt kəd bi soʊ fæsəneɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ə dɛd wʊmən? ə dɛd wʊmən. laɪt, meɪbi ðoʊz pipəl ɑn ðə ɹoʊd . . . ! noʊ; hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðəɾ əɾ ɔl.

Thom went by clutching his bronze-colored cloak around him, knuckling his long white mustaches and yawning as if he had spent the night awake. He might have. The gleeman had not taken to drink again, but Lopin and Nerim complained about him remaining awake till all hours, burning a lamp so he could read and re-read his precious letter. What could be so fascinating in a letter from a dead woman? A dead woman. Light, maybe those people on the road . . . ! No; he was not going to think about that at all.

tuɑn plʌkt wʌn foʊld ə sɪlk ən lɛɾ ɪt dʒɹɑp əz ʃi tɝn əweɪ wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ ənʌðɝ. sɪlutʃə ɡeɪv ðə staʊt ʃɑpkipɝ sətʃ ə stɛɹ bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ðət ðə wʊmən stɑɹɾəd bæk ɪn əfɹʌnt. mæt ɔfɝɾ əɹ ə smaɪl. əfɹʌntɪd ʃɑpkipɝz kəd lid tə taʊn ɡɑɹdz æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz, ən u kəd seɪ wɛɹ ðət maɪt lɛd? hi nu hi kəd smaɪl moʊst wɪmən ɪndə filɪŋ suðd. ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wʊmən snɪft əɾ ɪm ən bɛn tə smuðɪŋ ðə boʊlt ə sɪlk əz tɛndɝli əz tʌkɪŋ ɪn ə beɪb. moʊst wɪmən, hi θɔt saʊɝli.

Tuon plucked one fold of silk and let it drop as she turned away without trying another. Selucia gave the stout shopkeeper such a stare before following that the woman started back in affront. Mat offered her a smile. Affronted shopkeepers could lead to town guards asking questions, and who could say where that might lead? He knew he could smile most women into feeling soothed. The round-faced woman sniffed at him and bent to smoothing the bolt of silk as tenderly as tucking in a babe. Most women, he thought sourly.

daʊn ðə stʃɹit, ə wʊmən ɪn ə pleɪn kloʊk lɛɾ əɹ hʊd fɔl, ən mæts bɹɛθ kɑɾ ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

Down the street, a woman in a plain cloak let her hood fall, and Mat's breath caught in his throat.

idɛzinə lɪftəɾ əɹ kaʊl əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi tʊk noʊ hɝi wɪð ɪt, ən ðə dæmədʒ wɑz dʌn ɛniweɪ, ən ɛɛs sədaɪz eɪdʒləs feɪs dɪspleɪd fəɹ ɛniwʌn u nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ siɪŋ. noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə stʃɹit ɡeɪv ə saɪn ðət ðeɪ hæd noʊɾəst ɛniθɪŋ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt si ɛvɹi feɪs. wɑz ɛniwʌn θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ə ɹɪwɔɹd?

Edesina lifted her cowl again, but she took no hurry with it, and the damage was done anyway, an Aes Sedai's ageless face displayed for anyone who knew what they were seeing. No one in the street gave a sign that they had noticed anything, but he could not see every face. Was anyone thinking of a reward?

ðəɹ maɪt bi noʊ sintʃæn ɪn dʒʊɹədɔɹ ət ðə moʊmənt, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd pæs θɹu.

There might be no Seanchan in Jurador at the moment, but they did pass through.

idɛzinə ɡlaɪɾɪd ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ, ən tu dɑɹk-kloʊkt ʃeɪps fɑloʊd hɝ. tu. hæd ðə sʌldəm lɛft oʊnli wʌn ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ɪn ðə kæmp tə wɑtʃ tu ɛɛs sədaɪ? əɹ meɪbi dʒoʊlin əɹ tɛslɪn wɑz sʌmwɛɹ kloʊz baɪ, ən i hæd mɪst siɪŋ hɝ. hi kɹeɪn ɪz nɛk, sɝtʃɪŋ ðə θɹɔŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ pleɪn kloʊk, bʌɾ ɛvɹi wʌn i sɔ hæɾ ət list ə lɪɾəl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi.

Edesina glided around a corner, and two dark-cloaked shapes followed her. Two. Had the sul'dam left only one of their number in the camp to watch two Aes Sedai? Or maybe Joline or Teslyn was somewhere close by, and he had missed seeing her. He craned his neck, searching the throng for another plain cloak, but every one he saw had at least a little embroidery.

əbɹʌpli, ɪt hɪɾ ɪm laɪk ə stoʊn bɪtwin ði aɪz. ɛvɹi kloʊk i kəd si hæɾ ət list ə lɪɾəl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. wɛɹ wɝ blʌɾi tuɑn ən blʌɾi sɪlutʃə? wɝ ðə daɪs spɪnɪŋ fæstɝ? bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, hi wɛn ʌp ɑn ɪz toʊz, bʌt ðə stʃɹit wɑz ə ɹɪvɝ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kloʊks, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊts ən dʒɹɛsəz. ɪt dɪd nɑt min ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp. tuɑn hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɝd; ʃi hæd pæst ʌp ə pɝfək tʃæns fəɹ bɪtʃɹeɪəl. bʌɾ ɔl iðɝ wʊmən hæd tə də wɑz seɪ θɹi wɝdz, ən ɛniwʌn u hɝɾ əm laɪkli wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ə sintʃæn æksɛnt. ðət maɪt bi səfɪʃən tə sɛt ðə haʊnz ɑn ɪz tʃɹeɪl.

Abruptly, it hit him like a stone between the eyes. Every cloak he could see had at least a little embroidery. Where were bloody Tuon and bloody Selucia? Were the dice spinning faster? Breathing hard, he went up on his toes, but the street was a river of embroidered cloaks, embroidered coats and dresses. It did not mean they were trying to escape. Tuon had given her word; she had passed up a perfect chance for betrayal. But all either woman had to do was say three words, and anyone who heard them likely would recognize a Seanchan accent. That might be sufficient to set the hounds on his trail.

ðəɹ wɝ tu ʃɑps əhɛd ðət sim tə bi ɔfɝɪŋ klɔθ, wʌn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. niðɝ wɪð ə pɛɹ ə dɑɹk-kloʊkt wɪmən ət ðə teɪbəlz aʊt fɹʌnt. ðeɪ cʊɾə tɝn ə kɔɹnɝ izəli ɪnʌf, bʌɾ i hæd tə tʃɹʌs tə lʌk. hɪz lʌk wɑz ɪspɛʃli ɡʊd wən ðə ɡeɪm wɑz ɹændəm. blʌɾi wɪmən pɹɑbli θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə blʌɾi ɡeɪm. bɝn hɪm, lɛɾ ɪz lʌk ɹʌn ɡʊd.

There were two shops ahead that seemed to be offering cloth, one on either side of the street. Neither with a pair of dark-cloaked women at the tables out front. They could have turned a corner easily enough, but he had to trust to luck. His luck was especially good when the game was random. Bloody women probably thought it was a bloody game. Burn him, let his luck run good.

kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz, hi spʌn ɪn ə sɝkəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹiɾ ən tʊk ə stɛp. ət ɹændəm. hi bʌmpt ɪndə sʌmwʌn sɑləd, hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk əm boʊθ ɡɹʌnt. ə bʌlki fɛloʊ wɪð ə smɔl maʊθ ən ə lɪɾəl pʊɹli dʌn skɹɑlwɝk ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝz ə hɪz ɹʌf koʊt stʊd ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ən fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz kɝv naɪf. mæt dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hi wɑz feɪsɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət wʌn ə ðə tu ʃɑps. pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæt daʊn taɪt, hi ɹæn. ðə daɪs wɝ ɹoʊlɪŋ fæstɝ.

Closing his eyes, he spun in a circle in the middle of the street and took a step. At random. He bumped into someone solid, hard enough to make them both grunt. A bulky fellow with a small mouth and a little poorly done scrollwork on the shoulders of his rough coat stood glaring at him when he opened his eyes, glaring and fingering the hilt of his curved knife. Mat did not care. He was facing straight at one of the two shops. Pulling his hat down tight, he ran. The dice were rolling faster.

dɪvaɪɾəd ʃɛlvz stʌft wɪð boʊls ə klɔθ laɪn ðə wɔlz ə ðə ʃɑp fɹəm flɔɹ tə silɪŋ, ən mɔɹ stʊd stækt ɑn lɔŋ teɪbəlz aʊɾ ɪn ðə flɔɹ. ðə ʃɑpkipɝ wɑz ə skɹɔni wʊmən wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ moʊl ɑn əɹ tʃɪn, hɝ əsɪstən slɪm ən pɹɪɾi ən æŋɡɹjeɪd. hi dæʃt ɪnsaɪd dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə hɪɹ ðə ʃɑpkipɝ seɪ, "fɔɹ ðə læs taɪm, ɪf jə woʊn tɛl mi wʌt jəɹ hɪɹ fɔɹ, aɪm gɑnə sɛnd nɛlsə fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz." tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə, feɪsəz stɪl hɪɾən ɪn ðɛɹ hʊdz, wɝ wɔkɪŋ sloʊli əlɔŋ wʌn wɔl fʊl ə klɔθ, stɑpɪŋ tə tʌtʃ ə boʊl bʌt niðɝ peɪɪŋ ðə ʃɑpkipɝ ɛni hid.

Divided shelves stuffed with bolts of cloth lined the walls of the shop from floor to ceiling, and more stood stacked on long tables out in the floor. The shopkeeper was a scrawny woman with a large mole on her chin, her assistant slim and pretty and angryeyed. He dashed inside just in time to hear the shopkeeper say, "For the last time, if you won't tell me what you're here for, I'm going to send Nelsa for the guards." Tuon and Selucia, faces still hidden in their hoods, were walking slowly along one wall full of cloth, stopping to touch a bolt but neither paying the shopkeeper any heed.

"ðeɪɹ wɪð mi," mæt sɛd bɹɛθləsli. tʌɡɪŋ ðə pɝs fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, hi tɔst ɪɾ ɑn ðə nɪɹəs klɪɹ teɪbəl. ðə hɛvi klɪŋk ɪt meɪd lændɪŋ pʊɾ ə waɪd smaɪl ɑn ðə ʃɑpkipɝz nɛɹoʊ feɪs.

"They're with me," Mat said breathlessly. Tugging the purse from his pocket, he tossed it on the nearest clear table. The heavy clink it made landing put a wide smile on the shopkeeper's narrow face.

"ɡɪv əm wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɑnt," hi toʊl hɝ. ən tə tuɑn, hi æɾəd fɝmli, "ɪf jəɹ gɑnə baɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ɪts gɑnə bi hɪɹ. aɪv hæɾ ɔl ði ɛksɝsaɪz aɪ kɛɹ fəɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ." hi wʊɾə hæd ðə wɝdz bæk əz sun əz ðeɪ lɛft ɪz maʊθ, ɪf i kʊd. spik tə ə wʊmən ðət weɪ, ən ʃi flɛɹɾ ɪn jəɹ feɪs laɪk wʌn ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹəz faɪɹstɪks, ɛvɹi taɪm. bʌt tuɑnz bɪɡ aɪz lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə ʃɛltɝ ə hɝ hʊd. ən əɹ fʊl maʊθ kɝv slaɪtli ɪn ə smaɪl. ɪt wɑz ə sikɹət smaɪl, fəɹ hɝsɛlf, nɑt hɪm. ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt. hi heɪɾəd ɪt wən wɪmən dɪd ðæt. ət lis ðə daɪs hæd nɑt stɑpt. ðət hæd tə bi ə ɡʊd saɪn, ɹaɪt?

"Give them whatever they want," he told her. And to Tuon, he added firmly, "If you're going to buy anything, it's going to be here. I've had all the exercise I care for this morning." He would have had the words back as soon as they left his mouth, if he could. Speak to a woman that way, and she flared in your face like one of Aludra's firesticks, every time. But Tuon's big eyes looked up at him from the shelter of her hood. And her full mouth curved slightly in a smile. It was a secret smile, for herself, not him. The Light only knew what it meant. He hated it when women did that. At least the dice had not stopped. That had to be a good sign, right?

tuɑn hæd noʊ niɾ ʌv wɝdz tə meɪk əɹ tʃɔɪsəz, saɪlənli pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt boʊlt æftɝ boʊlt ən mɛʒɝɪŋ wɪð əɹ smɔl dɑɹk hænz haʊ mʌtʃ ðə ʃɑpkipɝ wɑz tə kʌɾ ɔf wɪð əɹ ʃiɹz. ðə wʊmən dɪd ðə wɝk hɝsɛlf ɪnstɛɾ ə dɛləɡeɪɾɪŋ ɪt tə hɝ əsɪstənt, ən wɛl ʃi maɪt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ.

Tuon had no need of words to make her choices, silently pointing out bolt after bolt and measuring with her small dark hands how much the shopkeeper was to cut off with her shears. The woman did the work herself instead of delegating it to her assistant, and well she might, considering.

ɹɛd sɪlk ɪn sɛvɹəl ʃeɪdz wɛn ʌndɝ ðoʊz lɔŋ ʃɑɹp sɪzɝz, ən ɡɹin sɪlk ɪn ə fju ʃeɪdz, ən mɔɹ vɝaɪəɾiz ə blu sɪlk ðən mæt nu ɪɡzɪstəd. tuɑn tʃoʊz aʊt səm faɪn lɪnən ɪn sɛvɹəl θɪknəsəz, ən lɛŋθs ə bɹaɪt wʊl - ʃi kənsʌltəd sɪlutʃə oʊvɝ ðoʊz ɪn mʌfəld wɪspɝz  - bʌt moʊsli ɪt wɑz sɪlk.

Red silk in several shades went under those long sharp scissors, and green silk in a few shades, and more varieties of blue silk than Mat knew existed. Tuon chose out some fine linen in several thicknesses, and lengths of bright wool - she consulted Selucia over those in muffled whispers  - but mostly it was silk.

hi ɡɑt bæk mʌtʃ lɛs ə hɪz pɝs ðən i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd.

He got back much less of his purse than he had expected.

wʌns ɔl ðət klɔθ hæd bɪn foʊldəɾ ən nitli taɪd, ðən bʌndəld ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒɝ lɛŋθ ə kɔɹs lɪnən - ət noʊ ɛkstʃɹə tʃɑɹdʒ, θæŋk jə vɛɹi mʌtʃ - ɪt meɪɾ ə maʊn əz fæɾ əz ə pɛdlɝz pæk. ɪt dɪd nɑt sɝpɹaɪz ɪm əɾ ɔl tə lɝn ðəɾ i wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə kæɹi ðə θɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, wɪð ɪz hæt dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɪn wʌn hænd. dʒɹɛs jəɹ bɛst, baɪ ə wʊmən sɪlk, ən ʃi stɪl faʊn ə weɪ tə meɪk jə wɝk!

Once all that cloth had been folded and neatly tied, then bundled into a larger length of coarse linen - at no extra charge, thank you very much - it made a mound as fat as a peddler's pack. It did not surprise him at all to learn that he was expected to carry the thing across his shoulders, with his hat dangling in one hand. Dress your best, buy a woman silk, and she still found a way to make you work!

meɪbi ʃi wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪm peɪ fəɹ spikɪŋ fɝmli.

Maybe she was making him pay for speaking firmly.

hi ɝn plɛnti ʌv stɛɹz fɹəm ɡeɪpɪŋ fulz əz i meɪɾ ɪz weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn bɪhaɪn ðə tu wɪmən. ðeɪ ɡlaɪɾɪd əlɔŋ smʌɡ əz kæts fʊl ə kɹim. ivən kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd, ðɛɹ bæks sɛɾ ɪɾ ɔl.

He earned plenty of stares from gaping fools as he made his way out of the town behind the two women. They glided along smug as cats full of cream. Even cloaked and hooded, their backs said it all.

ðə sʌn wɑz stɪl wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə mɪddeɪ, bʌt ðə laɪn ə pipəl weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə ʃoʊ stʃɹɛtʃt daʊn ðə ɹoʊɾ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə taʊn. moʊst ɡeɪpt ən pɔɪntəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ ə peɪntəd ful. wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ hɔɹs hænlɝz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə kɔɪn bɑks ɡeɪv ə ɡæp-tuθ smɝk ən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt mæt ɹɪtɝn ɪm ə lɛvəl lʊk, ən ðə fɛloʊ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pʊɾ ɪz aɪz bæk ɑn ðə kɔɪnz ɡoʊɪŋ fɹəm taʊnzfoʊk tə ɡlæs pɪtʃɝ tə bɑks. mæt θɔɾ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ ɹɪliv tə bi ɪnsaɪd lukəz ʃoʊ. bɪfɔɹ i ən ðə tu wɪmən hæd ɡɑɾən θɹi stɛps ɪnsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹəns, dʒulɪn keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ wɪθaʊt θɛɹə əɹ ɪz ɹɛd kæp. ðə θif-kætʃɝz feɪs cʊɾə bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm eɪntʃən oʊk. aɪɪŋ ðə pipəl floʊɪŋ pæst əm ɪndə ðə ʃoʊ, hi pɪtʃt ɪz vɔɪs loʊ. loʊ ən ɝdʒənt. "aɪ wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə faɪn ju. ɪts ɛdʒiənɪn; ʃiz bɪn . . . hɝt. kʌm kwɪkli."

The sun was still well short of midday, but the line of people waiting to get into the show stretched down the road almost to the town. Most gaped and pointed as if he were a painted fool. One of the big horse handlers guarding the coin box gave a gap-toothed smirk and opened his mouth, but Mat returned him a level look, and the fellow decided to put his eyes back on the coins going from townsfolk to glass pitcher to box. Mat thought he had never been so relieved to be inside Luca's show. Before he and the two women had gotten three steps inside the entrance, Juilin came running up, for a wonder without Thera or his red cap. The thief-catcher's face could have been carved from ancient oak. Eyeing the people flowing past them into the show, he pitched his voice low. Low and urgent. "I was coming to find you. It's Egeanin; she's been . . . hurt. Come quickly."

ðə mænz toʊn sɛɾ ɪnʌf, bʌt wɝs, mæt ɹilaɪz ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd wɝ dʒɹʌmɪŋ, naʊ.

The man's tone said enough, but worse, Mat realized the dice in his head were drumming, now.

hi flʌŋ ðə pæk ə klɔθ ət ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz wɪð ə heɪsti ɪndʒʌŋkʃən tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪɾ əz kloʊs əz ðə kɔɪn-bɑks əɹ i wəd sɛt ðə wɪmən ɑn ðɛm, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt weɪt tə si wɛðɝ ðeɪ tʊk ɪm sɪɹiəsli.

He flung the pack of cloth at the horse handlers with a hasty injunction to guard it as close as the coin-box or he would set the women on them, but he did not wait to see whether they took him seriously.

dʒulɪn dɑɹɾɪd bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm əɾ ə ɹʌn, ən mæt ɹæn æftɝ hɪm, əlɔŋ ðə waɪd meɪn stʃɹiɾ ə ðə ʃoʊ wɛɹ nɔɪzi ɡɔkɪŋ kɹaʊdz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə fɔɹ bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd tʃeɪvænə bɹʌðɝz stæn ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝz, ən kəntɔɹʃənɪsts ɪn fɪlmi tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ vɛsts sɪɾ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn hɛdz, ən ə slæk-ɹoʊp wɔkɝ ɪn spæŋɡəl blu bɹitʃɪz klaɪmɪŋ ə lɔŋ wʊɾən læɾɝ tə bɪɡɪn əɹ pɝfɔɹməns.

Juilin darted back the way he had come at a run, and Mat ran after him, along the wide main street of the show where noisy gawking crowds were watching the four bare-chested Chavana brothers stand on one another's shoulders, and contortionists in filmy trousers and glittering vests sit on their own heads, and a slack-rope walker in spangled blue breeches climbing a long wooden ladder to begin her performance.

ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə slæk-ɹoʊp wɔkɝ, dʒulɪn dɑdʒd ɪndə wʌn ə ðə nɛɹoʊɝ stʃɹits, wɛɹ lɔnʒɹi hʌŋ fɹəm laɪnz bɪtwin ðə tɛns ən wæɡənz, pɝfɔɹmɝz sæɾ ɑn stulz ən wæɡən stɛps weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɑn, ən haʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ɹæn pleɪɪŋ wɪð bɔlz ən hups. mæt nu wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾəd, naʊ, bʌt ðə θif-kætʃɝ ɹæn tu fæs tə oʊvɝteɪk. əhɛd, hi sɔ hɪz ɡɹin wæɡən. lətɛl wɑz piɹɪŋ ʌndɝniθ, ən lukə, ɪn wʌn ə hɪz bɹaɪt ɹɛd kloʊks, wɑz weɪvɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə dʒʌɡəlɝz tə muv əlɔŋ. ðə tu wɪmən, ɪn bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz ən wɪð feɪsəz peɪntəd waɪt laɪk ə noʊbəlz fulz, tʊk ə ɡʊd lʊk ʌndɝ ðə wæɡən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ oʊbeɪd. əz i keɪm kloʊsɝ, hi kəd si wʌt ðeɪ hæd ðeɪ bɪn stɛɹɪŋ æt. koʊtləs, doʊmən wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wæɡən, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ə lɪmp ɛdʒiənɪn ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. hɝ aɪz wɝ kloʊzd, ən ə tʃɹɪkəl ə blʌd ɹæn fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ əɹ maʊð. hɝ wɪɡ hʌŋ əskju. ðət stʊɾ aʊt, fəɹ səm ɹizən. ʃi ɔlweɪz fʌst soʊ tə kip ðət wɪɡ stʃɹeɪt. ðə daɪs bit laɪk θʌndɝ.

Short of the slack-rope walker, Juilin dodged into one of the narrower streets, where laundry hung from lines between the tents and wagons, performers sat on stools and wagon steps waiting to go on, and how children ran playing with balls and hoops. Mat knew where they were headed, now, but the thief-catcher ran too fast to overtake. Ahead, he saw his green wagon. Latelle was peering underneath, and Luca, in one of his bright red cloaks, was waving a pair of jugglers to move along. The two women, in baggy trousers and with faces painted white like a noble's fools, took a good look under the wagon before they obeyed. As he came closer, he could see what they had they been staring at. Coatless, Domon was sitting on the ground under the edge of the wagon, cradling a limp Egeanin in his arms. Her eyes were closed, and a trickle of blood ran from the corner her mouth. Her wig hung askew. That stood out, for some reason. She always fussed so to keep that wig straight. The dice beat like thunder.

"ðɪs kəd bi dɪzæstɝ," lukə ɡɹaʊld, splɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɡlaʊɝ bɪtwin mæt ən dʒulɪn. ɪt wɑz ən æŋɡɹi ɡlaʊɝ, ðoʊ, nɑt fɹaɪɾənd. "ju meɪ hæv bɹɔt mi tə dɪzæstɝ!" hi ʃuɾ əweɪ ə ɡæɡəl ʌv waɪd-aɪd tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ɡɹaʊld əɾ ə plʌmp wʊmən ɪn skɝts ðət ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ wɪð sɪlvɝi spæŋɡəlz.

"This could be disaster," Luca growled, splitting his glower between Mat and Juilin. It was an angry glower, though, not frightened. "You may have brought me to disaster!" He shooed away a gaggle of wide-eyed children, and growled at a plump woman in skirts that glittering with silvery spangles.

maɪaɪɔɹə meɪd lɛpɝdz də tʃɹɪks ðəɾ ivən lətɛl wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ, bʌt ʃi mɪɹli tɔst əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ ɡlaɪɾɪŋ ɔf. noʊ wʌn tʊk lukə əz sɪɹiəsli əz i tʊk hɪmsɛlf.

Miyora made leopards do tricks that even Latelle would not try, but she merely tossed her head before gliding off. No one took Luca as seriously as he took himself.

ðə mæn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə hɝiɾ ʌp, ən lʊkt ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɛlɪŋ əm tə ɡoʊ, tu, bɪfɔɹ i θɔt bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪt. ɪn fækt, hi bɪɡæn tə fɹaʊn θɔtfəli. ən wɝidli. ɪt simd ɪz waɪf hæd nɑt toʊld ɪm əbaʊt mæt ən ðə wɪmən livɪŋ ðə ʃoʊ, ən ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn sʌmwɛɹ. ðə blu-aɪd wʊmən hæd ðə hjudʒ bʌndəl ə klɔθ ɑn əɹ bæk naʊ, wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz dʌbəl bɪhaɪn hɝ, ðoʊ ʃi stʊd stʃɹeɪt dɪspaɪt ðə bʌlk. jə wəd θɪŋk ə leɪɾiz meɪd wɑz juz tə kæɹiɪŋ θɪŋz, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz ə pɪktʃɝ ə fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd ɪɹɪteɪʃən. lətɛl aɪɾ əɹ ʌp ən daʊn, ðən snɪɹɾ ət mæt əz ɪf i wɝ ðə ɹizən ðə wʊmən wɑz θɹʌstɪŋ əɹ kənsɪɾɝəbəl bʊzəm aʊt. lukəz waɪf wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət snɪɹɪŋ, jɛt tuɑnz stɝn ɪkspɹɛʃən meɪd lətɛl nɪɹli lʊk maɪld. ə dʒʌdʒ pɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ kaʊl, ə dʒʌdʒ ɹɛɾi tə pæs sɛntəns.

The man gave a start when Tuon and Selucia hurried up, and looked on the point of telling them to go, too, before he thought better of it. In fact, he began to frown thoughtfully. And worriedly. It seemed his wife had not told him about Mat and the women leaving the show, and it was clear they had been somewhere. The blue-eyed woman had the huge bundle of cloth on her back now, with her arms doubled behind her, though she stood straight despite the bulk. You would think a lady's maid was used to carrying things, but her face was a picture of frustrated irritation. Latelle eyed her up and down, then sneered at Mat as if he were the reason the woman was thrusting her considerable bosom out. Luca's wife was very good at sneering, yet Tuon's stern expression made Latelle nearly look mild. A judge peered out of her cowl, a judge ready to pass sentence.

fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, mæt dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌt ðə wɪmən θɔt.

For the moment, Mat did not care what the women thought.

ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs. tɔsɪŋ ɪz kloʊk bæk, hi wɛn tə wʌn ni ən tʌtʃt fɪŋɡɝz tə ɛdʒiənɪnz θɹoʊt. hɝ pʌls bit wikli, θɪn ən flʌɾɝɪŋ.

Those bloody dice. Tossing his cloak back, he went to one knee and touched fingers to Egeanin's throat. Her pulse beat weakly, thin and fluttering.

"wʌt hæpənd?" hi æskt. "hæv jə sɛn fəɹ wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz?" muvɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪn maɪt bi ɪnʌf tə kɪl hɝ, bʌt ðəɹ maɪt bi taɪm fəɹ hilɪŋ, ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ kwɪk. hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə seɪ ðət neɪm əlaʊd, ðoʊ, wɪð pipəl wɔkɪŋ baɪ, pɔzɪŋ fəɹ kjʊɹiəs stɛɹz bɪfɔɹ lukə əɹ lətɛl hɝiɾ əm ɑn. ɛvɹiwʌn muv kwɪkɝ fəɹ əɹ ðən fəɹ hɪm. lətɛl hɝsɛlf wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u ɹɪli dʒʌmp fəɹ lukə.

"What happened?" he asked. "Have you sent for one of the sisters?" Moving Egeanin might be enough to kill her, but there might be time for Healing, if the Aes Sedai were quick. He was not about to say that name aloud, though, with people walking by, pausing for curious stares before Luca or Latelle hurried them on. Everyone moved quicker for her than for him. Latelle herself was the only one who really jumped for Luca.

"ɹɛnə!" doʊmən spæt ðə neɪm. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz ʃɔɹt kæp ə hɛɹ ən ðəɾ ɪliɑnɝ bɪɹd ðət lɛft ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ, hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ɹɪdɪkjələs, naʊ. hi lʊkt əfɹeɪɾ ən mɝɾɝəs, ə deɪnʒɝəs kɑmbəneɪʃən. "aɪ dɪd si hɝ stæb ɛdʒiənɪn ɪn ðə bæk ən ɹʌn. ɪf aɪ cʊɾə ɹitʃt hɝ, aɪ wʊɾə bɹoʊkən əɹ nɛk, bʌt maɪ hæn bi ɔl ðæts hoʊldɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪnz blʌɾ ɪn. wɛɹ bi ðət blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ?" hi snɑɹəld. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ biɪŋ kɛɹfəl wɪð ɪz tʌŋ.

"Renna!" Domon spat the name. Despite his short cap of hair and that Illianer beard that left his upper lip bare, he did not look ridiculous, now. He looked afraid and murderous, a dangerous combination. "I did see her stab Egeanin in the back and run. If I could have reached her, I would have broken her neck, but my hand be all that's holding Egeanin's blood in. Where be that bloody Aes Sedai?" he snarled. So much for being careful with his tongue.

"aɪ bi ɹaɪt hɪɹ, beɪl doʊmən," tɛslɪn ənaʊns koʊldli, ɹʌʃɪŋ ʌp wɪð θɛɹə, hu tʊk wʌn hɔɹəfaɪd lʊk ət tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə ən lætʃt ɑn tə dʒulɪnz ɑɹm wɪð ə skwik, aɪz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə weɪ ʃi bɪɡæn tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ʃi maɪt bi ðəɹ hɝsɛlf ɪn ə mɪnət.

"I be right here, Bayle Domon," Teslyn announced coldly, rushing up with Thera, who took one horrified look at Tuon and Selucia and latched on to Juilin's arm with a squeak, eyes on the ground. The way she began trembling, she might be there herself in a minute.

ðə hɑɹd-aɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪɾ ə feɪs əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ə maʊθfʊl ə bɹaɪɹz wən ʃi sɔ wʌt leɪ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, əɹ meɪbi wɛɹ ɪt leɪ, bʌt ʃi swɪfli kɹaʊtʃt ʌndɝniθ ðə wæɡən bɪsaɪd doʊmən ən klæspt ɛdʒiənɪnz hɛɾ ɪn əɹ boʊni hænz. "dʒoʊlin də bi bɛɾɝ ət ðɪs ðən aɪ," ʃi mʌɾɝd, hɔlt ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, "bʌɾ aɪ meɪ bi eɪbəl - " ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd wɛn koʊld əɡɛns mæts tʃɛst, ən ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɝk soʊ vaɪələnli ðəɾ əɹ wɪɡ fɛl ɔf, nɪɹli pʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə doʊmənz ɡɹæsp əz əɹ aɪz pɑpt oʊpən waɪd. ðə kənvʌlʃən læstəɾ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ tə sɪt hæfweɪ ʌp wɪð ə fɹoʊzən ɡæsp; ðən ʃi slʌmp bæk əɡɛns doʊmənz tʃɛst, pæntɪŋ, ən ðə mədæljən bɪkeɪm dʒʌst ə pis ʌv wɝk sɪlvɝ əɡɛn. hi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əkʌstəm tə ðæt. hi heɪɾəd biɪŋ əkʌstəm tə ðæt. tɛslɪn slʌmpt, tu, ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə fɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ əntɪl doʊmən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ɛdʒiənɪn tə stɛɾi ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð wʌn hænd.

The hard-eyed Aes Sedai made a face as if she had a mouthful of briars when she saw what lay in front of her, or maybe where it lay, but she swiftly crouched underneath the wagon beside Domon and clasped Egeanin's head in her bony hands. "Joline do be better at this than I," she muttered, halt under her breath, "but I may be able - " The silver foxhead went cold against Mat's chest, and Egeanin jerked so violently that her wig fell off, nearly pulling herself out of Domon's grasp as her eyes popped open wide. The convulsion lasted only long enough for her to sit halfway up with a frozen gasp; then she slumped back against Domon's chest, panting, and the medallion became just a piece of worked silver again. He was almost accustomed to that. He hated being accustomed to that. Teslyn slumped, too, on the point of falling over until Domon shifted his grip on Egeanin to steady the Aes Sedai with one hand.

"θæŋk ju," tɛslɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðə wɝdz saʊndɪŋ dʒɹæɡd fɹəm hɝ. "bʌɾ aɪ nid noʊ hɛlp." ʃi juz ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən tə hɛlp əɹ ɹaɪz, ðoʊ, hɝ koʊld ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪz dɛɹɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə kɑmɛnt. "ðə bleɪd dɪd slaɪɾ ɑn ə ɹɪb ən soʊ dɪd mɪs əɹ hɑɹt. ɔl ʃi dʌz nid naʊ bi ɹɛst ən fud." ʃi hæd nɑt dɪleɪd tə ɡɹæb ə kloʊk, mæt ɹilaɪzd. ɪn wʌn dɝɛkʃən əlɔŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹit, ə klʌtʃ ʌv wɪmən ɪn spæŋɡəl kloʊks wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə ɡɹin-stʃɹaɪp tɛnt, ðɛɹ ɡeɪzəz ɪntɛn ən foʊkəst. ɪn ði ʌðɝ, hæf ə dʌzən mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn waɪt-stʃɹaɪp koʊts ən taɪt bɹitʃɪz, ækɹəbæts u pɝfɔɹmd ɑn hɔɹsbæk, dɑɹɾɪd lʊks təwɔɹd tɛslɪn bɪtwin pʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ tə wɪspɝ. tu leɪt tə wɝi əbaʊt sʌmwʌn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs. tu leɪt tə wɝi ðət wʌn ə ðɛm nu hilɪŋ wən i sɔ ɪt dʌn. ðə daɪs bæɾɝd ət ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə mæts hɛd. ðeɪ hæd nɑt stɑpt; ðə ɡeɪm wɑz nɑt pleɪɾ aʊt, jɛt. "huz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, dʒulɪn?" hi æskt. "dʒulɪn?" ðə θif-kætʃɝ ɡeɪv oʊvɝ ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə ən mɝmɝɪŋ tə θɛɹə, ðoʊ hi kəntɪnjud tə pæt ðə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ wʊmən. "veɪnɪn ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, ləpɪn ən nɹɪm. oʊlvɝ, tu. hi wɑz əweɪ bɪfɔɹ aɪ kəd kætʃ hɪm. bʌɾ ɪn ðɪs. . . ." hi stɑp suðɪŋ θɛɹə lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɛstʃɝ təwɔɹd ðə meɪn stʃɹit. ðə bæbəl ə vɔɪsəz wɑz klɪɹli ɑɾəbəl ivən ət ðɪs dɪstəns. "ɔl ʃi nidz ɪz tə leɪ hænz ɑn wʌn ə ðoʊz fænsi kloʊks, ən ʃi kən slɪp aʊt wɪð ðə fɝs foʊk tə liv. ɪf wi tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ ɛvɹi wʊmən wɪð əɹ hʊɾ ʌp, əɹ ivən tʃɹaɪ lʊkɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, wɪl əv ə ɹaɪəɾ ɑn əɹ hænz. ðiz pipəl ɑɹ tʌtʃi." "dɪzæstɝ," lukə moʊnd, ɹæpɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf taɪtli. lətɛl pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɪm. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn laɪk biɪŋ kʌmfɝɾɪd baɪ ə lɛpɝd, bʌɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs, lukə dɪd nɑt lʊk mʌtʃ kʌmfɝɾɪd.

"Thank you," Teslyn said after a moment, the words sounding dragged from her. "But I need no help." She used the side of the wagon to help her rise, though, her cold Aes Sedai gaze daring anyone to comment. "The blade did slide on a rib and so did miss her heart. All she does need now be rest and food." She had not delayed to grab a cloak, Mat realized. In one direction along the narrow street, a clutch of women in spangled cloaks was watching from in front of a green-striped tent, their gazes intent and focused. In the other, half a dozen men and women in white-striped coats and tight breeches, acrobats who performed on horseback, darted looks toward Teslyn between putting their heads together to whisper. Too late to worry about someone recognizing an Aes Sedai's face. Too late to worry that one of them knew Healing when he saw it done. The dice battered at the inside of Mat's head. They had not stopped; the game was not played out, yet. "Who's looking for her, Juilin?" he asked. "Juilin?" The thief-catcher gave over glaring at Tuon and Selucia and murmuring to Thera, though he continued to pat the trembling woman. "Vanin and the Redarms, Lopin and Nerim. Olver, too. He was away before I could catch him. But in this. . . ." He stopped soothing Thera long enough to gesture toward the main street. The babble of voices was clearly audible even at this distance. "All she needs is to lay hands on one of those fancy cloaks, and she can slip out with the first folk to leave. If we try stopping every woman with her hood up, or even try looking inside, we'll have a riot on our hands. These people are touchy." "Disaster," Luca moaned, wrapping his cloak around himself tightly. Latelle put an arm around him. It must have been like being comforted by a leopard, but in any case, Luca did not look much comforted.

"bɝn mi, waɪ?" mæt ɡɹaʊld. "ɹɛnə wɑz ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi tə lɪk maɪ blʌɾi ɹɪst! aɪ θɔɾ ɪf ɛnibəɾi wɛn oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ . . . !" hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɡlæns ət θɛɹə, bʌt dʒulɪn stɪl skaʊld əɾ ɪm dɑɹkli.

"Burn me, why?" Mat growled. "Renna was always ready to lick my bloody wrist! I thought if anybody went over the edge . . . !" He did not even glance at Thera, but Juilin still scowled at him darkly.

doʊmən hæd stʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛdʒiənɪn ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl fibli ət fɝst - ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən tə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi kæɹiɾ əbaʊt laɪk ə dɑl - bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ʃi sim tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd meɪk əɹ oʊn fit, ʃi wəd fɔl oʊvɝ. ʃi sæɡd əɡɛns ði ɪliɑnɝz tʃɛst wɪð ə ɹɪzɛnfəl ɡlaʊɝ.

Domon had stood up with Egeanin in his arms. She struggled feebly at first - Egeanin was not a woman to let herself be carried about like a doll - but eventually she seemed to realize that if she did make her own feet, she would fall over. She sagged against the Illianer's chest with a resentful glower.

doʊmən wəd lɝn; ivən wən ə wʊmən niɾəd hɛlp, ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪt, ʃi meɪd jə peɪ fəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ɪt. "ɪm ði oʊnli wʌn u nu hɝ sikɹət," ʃi dʒɹɔld ɪn ə wik vɔɪs. "ði oʊnli wʌn u maɪt ɡɪv ɪɾ əweɪ, ət list. ʃi meɪ hæv θɔɾ ɪt wəd bi seɪf tə ɡoʊ hoʊm, wɪð mi dɛd."

Domon would learn; even when a woman needed help, if she did not want it, she made you pay for giving it. "I'm the only one who knew her secret," she drawled in a weak voice. "The only one who might give it away, at least. She may have thought it would be safe to go home, with me dead."

"wʌt sikɹət?" mæt æskt.

"What secret?" Mat asked.

ðə wʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fəɹ səm ɹizən, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət dimənz tʃɛst. faɪnəli ʃi saɪd. "ɹɛnə wɑz liʃt, wʌns. soʊ wɝ bɛθəmən ən sɛɾə. ðeɪ kən tʃænəl. əɹ meɪbi lɝn tə; aɪ doʊnt noʊ. bʌt ði æɾəm wɝkt ɑn ðoʊz θɹi. meɪbi ɪt wɝks ɑn ɛni sʌldəm." mæt wɪsəl θɹu hɪz tiθ.

The woman hesitated, for some reason, frowning at Demon's chest. Finally she sighed. "Renna was leashed, once. So were Bethamin and Seta. They can channel. Or maybe learn to; I don't know. But the a'dam worked on those three. Maybe it works on any sul'dam." Mat whistled through his teeth.

naʊ, ðət wəd bi ə kɪk ɪn ðə hɛd fəɹ ðə sintʃæn.

Now, that would be a kick in the head for the Seanchan.

lukə ən ɪz waɪf ɪkstʃeɪnʒd pʌzəld ɡlænsɪz, pleɪnli nɑɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ ə wɝd. tɛslɪnz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən, ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝɛnəɾi wɑʃt əweɪ ɪn ʃɑk. sɪlutʃə meɪɾ ən æŋɡɹi saʊnd, ðoʊ, blu aɪz bleɪzɪŋ, ən dʒɹɑp ðə bʌndəl ə klɔθ fɹəm əɹ bæk əz ʃi tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd doʊmən. ə kwɪk flæʃ ə tuɑnz fɪŋɡɝz stɑpt əɹ ɪn əɹ tʃɹæks, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ə kwɪvɝɪŋ hɔlt. tuɑnz feɪs wɑz ə dɑɹk mæsk, ənɹiɾəbəl. ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk wʌt ʃi hæd hɝd, ðoʊ. kʌm tə θɪŋk, ʃi hæd sɛd ʃi tʃɹeɪn deɪmeɪn. oʊ, bɝn hɪm, ɑn tɑp ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, hi wɑz gɑnə mɛɹi ə wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl?

Luca and his wife exchanged puzzled glances, plainly not understanding a word. Teslyn's mouth hung open, Aes Sedai serenity washed away in shock. Selucia made an angry sound, though, blue eyes blazing, and dropped the bundle of cloth from her back as she took a step toward Domon. A quick flash of Tuon's fingers stopped her in her tracks, though it was a quivering halt. Tuon's face was a dark mask, unreadable. She did not like what she had heard, though. Come to think, she had said she trained damane. Oh, burn him, on top of everything else, he was going to marry a woman who could channel?

ðə saʊn ə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz ənaʊns hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi ɹɛdʒɹmz kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ weɪ bɪtwin ðə tɛns ən wæɡənz əɾ ə kwɪk tʃɹɑt. ðɛɹ sɔɹdz wɝ bɛltəɾ ɑn ʌndɝ ðɛɹ kloʊks, mɛtwɪn wɪð ə dæɡɝ ɔlmoʊst əz lɔŋ əz ə ʃɔɹt-sɔɹd tə but, ən ɡɔɹɾɝən hæɾ ɪz hɛvi kɹɔsboʊ hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪz sæɾəl, ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔn ən lætʃt. ðə kɹæŋk əɾ ɪz bɛlt wəd teɪk ə fʊl mɪnət tə pʊl bæk ðə θɪk kɔɹd, bʌt ðɪs weɪ, ɔl i nid də wɑz pleɪs ə boʊlt. hɑɹnən kæɹiɾ ə dʌbəl-kɝv hɔɹsboʊ, wɪð ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz hɪp. fɝdʒɪn wɑz liɾɪŋ pɪps.

The sound of horses' hooves announced Harnan and the other three Redarms coming along the narrow way between the tents and wagons at a quick trot. Their swords were belted on under their cloaks, Metwyn with a dagger almost as long as a short-sword to boot, and Gorderan had his heavy crossbow hanging at his saddle, already drawn and latched. The crank at his belt would take a full minute to pull back the thick cord, but this way, all he need do was place a bolt. Harnan carried a double-curve horsebow, with a bristling quiver at his hip. Fergin was leading Pips.

hɑɹnən dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ dɪsmaʊntɪŋ. aɪɪŋ tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə səspɪʃəsli, ən lukə ən lətɛl wɪð ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ daʊt, hi lin daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, ðə kɹud hɔk tætu ʃɑɹp ɑn ɪz tʃik.

Harnan did not bother dismounting. Eyeing Tuon and Selucia suspiciously, and Luca and Latelle with almost as much doubt, he leaned down from his saddle, the crude hawk tattoo sharp on his cheek.

"ɹɛnə stoʊl ə hɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɹoʊd daʊn wʌn ə ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz ət ði ɛntʃɹəns ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt. veɪnɪnz fɑloʊɪŋ hɝ. hi sɛz ʃi kəd ɹitʃ kɔɹəmən səm taɪm tənaɪt.

"Renna stole a horse, my Lord," he said quietly. "Rode down one of the horse handlers at the entrance getting out. Vanin's following her. He says she could reach Coramen some time tonight.

ðæts ðə weɪ ʃi hɛɾəd. ʃiz muvɪŋ ə lɑt fæstɝ ðən ðə wæɡənz dɪd. bʌt ʃiz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bæɹbæk; wi kən kætʃ hɝ, wɪð lʌk." hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðət lʌk wɝ ə mæɾɝ ə fækt. ðə mɛn ə ðə bæn tʃɹʌstɪd mæt kɔθənz lʌk mɔɹ ðən i dɪd hɪmsɛlf. ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɛni tʃɔɪsəz, ɹɪli.

That's the way she headed. She's moving a lot faster than the wagons did. But she's riding bareback; we can catch her, with luck." He sounded as if that luck were a matter of fact. The men of the Band trusted Mat Cauthon's luck more than he did himself. There did not seem to be any choices, really.

ðə daɪs wɝ stɪl paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə tʃæns ðeɪ maɪt fɔl ɪz weɪ. ə smɔl tʃæns. mæt kɔθənz lʌk. "ɡɛt jəɹ pipəl ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kən pæk ʌp, lukə," hi sɛd, stɛpɪŋ ʌp ɑntu pɪps. "liv ðə wɔl ən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls jə kænt ɡɛɾ ɑntu ðə wæɡənz fæst. dʒʌst ɡoʊ."

The dice were still pounding in his head. There was still a chance they might fall his way. A small chance. Mat Cauthon's luck. "Get your people on the road as fast as they can pack up, Luca," he said, stepping up onto Pips. "Leave the wall and anything else you can't get onto the wagons fast. Just go."

"ɑɹ jə kɹeɪzi?" lukə spləɾɝd. "ɪf aɪ tʃɹaɪ tə tʃeɪs ðoʊz pipəl aʊt, əl əv ə ɹaɪət! ən ðəl wɑn ðɛɹ kɔɪn bæk!" laɪt, ðə mæn wəd θɪŋk ə mʌni wɪð ɪz nɛk stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn ðə hɛdzmənz blɑk.

"Are you crazy?" Luca spluttered. "If I try to chase those people out, I will have a riot! And they'll want their coin back!" Light, the man would think of money with his neck stretched on the headsman's block.

"θɪŋk wʌt jəl əv ɪf ə θaʊzən sintʃæn faɪn jə hɪɹ təmɑɹoʊ." mæts vɔɪs wɑz əz koʊld əz i kəd meɪk ɪt. ɪf i feɪld, ðə sintʃæn wəd ɹʌn lukəz ʃoʊ daʊn ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɔɹɾɝ haʊɛvɝ fæs ðeɪ flɑɡd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. lukə nu ɪt, tu, fɹəm ðə twɪst ə hɪz maʊθ, əz ɪf i hæd dʒʌs bɪɾən ə ɹɑɾɪŋ plʌm. mæt meɪd hɪmsɛlf ɪɡnɔɹ ðə mæn. ðə daɪs wɝ dʒɹʌmɪŋ hɑɹd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd nɑt stɑp jɛt. "dʒulɪn, liv ɔl ðə ɡoʊl fəɹ lukə ɪksɛpt wʌn ɡʊd pɝs." meɪbi ðə mæn kəd bɹaɪb ɪz weɪ klɪɹ, wʌns ðə sintʃæn sɔ hi dɪd nɑɾ əv ðɛɹ dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn blʌɾi munz. "ɡæðɝ ɛvɹibɑɾi ən ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ əz sun əz jə kæn. wʌns jəɹ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊn, teɪk tə ðə fɔɹəst. əl faɪn ju."

"Think what you'll have if a thousand Seanchan find you here tomorrow." Mat's voice was as cold as he could make it. If he failed, the Seanchan would run Luca's show down in short order however fast they flogged their horses. Luca knew it, too, from the twist of his mouth, as if he had just bitten a rotting plum. Mat made himself ignore the man. The dice were drumming hard, but they had not stopped yet. "Juilin, leave all the gold for Luca except one good purse." Maybe the man could bribe his way clear, once the Seanchan saw he did not have their Daughter of the Nine bloody Moons. "Gather everybody and ride out as soon as you can. Once you're out of sight of the town, take to the forest. I'll find you."

"ɛvɹibɑɾi?" ʃɛltɝɪŋ θɛɹə wɪð ɪz bɑɾi, dʒulɪn dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd tuɑn ən sɪlutʃə.

"Everybody?" Sheltering Thera with his body, Juilin jerked his head toward Tuon and Selucia.

"liv ðoʊz tu ɪn dʒʊɹədɔɹ, ən ðə sintʃæn maɪt stɑp wɪð ɡɛɾɪŋ əm bæk. ɪt maɪt sloʊ ðɛm daʊn, ət list. jə kip seɪɪŋ jəɹ gɑnə tɝn əm lus sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ." mæt mɛt tuɑnz aɪz. bɪɡ dɑɹk lɪkwəɾ aɪz, ɪn ə smuð ɪkspɹɛʃənləs feɪs. ʃi hæd pʊʃt əɹ hʊd bæk ə lɪɾəl, soʊ hi kəd si hɝ feɪs klɪɹli. ɪf i lɛft əɹ bɪhaɪnd, ðən ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ ðə wɝdz, əɹ ɪf ʃi dɪd, hi wəd bi tu fɑɹ weɪ fəɹ ðə wɝdz tə mæɾɝ. ɪf i lɛft əɹ bɪhaɪnd, hi wəd nɛvɝ lɝn waɪ ʃi smaɪl ðoʊz mɪstɪɹiəs smaɪlz, əɹ wʌt leɪ bɪhaɪn ðə mɪstɝi. laɪt, hi wɑz ə ful! pɪps dænst ə fju ɪmpeɪʃən stɛps.

"Leave those two in Jurador, and the Seanchan might stop with getting them back. It might slow them down, at least. You keep saying you're going to turn them loose sooner or later." Mat met Tuon's eyes. Big dark liquid eyes, in a smooth expressionless face. She had pushed her hood back a little, so he could see her face clearly. If he left her behind, then she could not say the words, or if she did, he would be too far way for the words to matter. If he left her behind, he would never learn why she smiled those mysterious smiles, or what lay behind the mystery. Light, he was a fool! Pips danced a few impatient steps.

"ɛvɹibɑɾi," hi sɛd. dɪd tuɑn nɑd slaɪtli, əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf?

"Everybody," he said. Did Tuon nod slightly, as if to herself?

waɪ wəd ʃi nɑd? "lɛts ɹaɪd," hi toʊl hɑɹnən. ðeɪ hæd tə wɔk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃoʊ, bʌɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə ɹoʊd, mæt pʊt pɪps tə ə ɡæləp, kloʊk stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪn ən hɛd daʊn tə kip ɪz hæt fɹəm bloʊɪŋ ɔf. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə peɪs jə kəd kip ə hɔɹs ət fəɹ lɔŋ. ðə ɹoʊd waʊn ɝaʊn hɪlz ən kɹɔst ɹɪdʒəz, əkeɪʒənəli kʌɾɪŋ θɹu wɛɹ ðə ɹaɪz wɑz nɑt tu haɪ. ðeɪ splæʃt əkɹɔs æŋkəl-dip stʃɹimz ən θʌndɝɾ oʊvɝ loʊ wʊɾən bɹɪdʒəz kɹɔsɪŋ dipɝ wɔɾɝ. tʃɹiz bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ ɑn ðə sloʊps əɡɛn, paɪn ən lɛðɝlif ʃoʊɪŋ ɡɹin əmʌŋ ðə wɪntɝ-bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz ə ði ʌðɝz. fɑɹmz klʌŋ tə səm ə ðə hɪlz, loʊ taɪlɝuf stoʊn haʊsəz ən tɔlɝ bɑɹnz, ən naʊ ən ðən ə hæmləɾ ʌv eɪɾ əɹ tɛn haʊsəz.

Why would she nod? "Let's ride," he told Harnan. They had to walk their horses through the crowds to get out of the show, but as soon as they reached the road, Mat put Pips to a gallop, cloak streaming behind and head down to keep his hat from blowing off. It was not a pace you could keep a horse at for long. The road wound around hills and crossed ridges, occasionally cutting through where the rise was not too high. They splashed across ankle-deep streams and thundered over low wooden bridges crossing deeper water. Trees began to appear on the slopes again, pine and leatherleaf showing green among the winter-bare branches of the others. Farms clung to some of the hills, low tileroofed stone houses and taller barns, and now and then a hamlet of eight or ten houses.

ə fju maɪlz fɹəm ðə ʃoʊ, mæt spɑɾəd ə waɪd mæn əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, sɪɾɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl laɪk ə sæk ə sut. ðə hɔɹs wɑz ə lɛɡi dʌn, iɾɪŋ ɡɹaʊn əɾ ə stɛɾi tʃɹɑt. ɪt fɪɡjɝd ðəɾ ə hɔɹs θif hæɾ ən aɪ fəɹ ə ɡʊɾ ænəməl. kætʃɪŋ ðə saʊn ə ðɛɹ hʊvz, veɪnɪn lʊk bæk, bʌɾ i oʊnli sloʊd tə ə wɔk.

A few miles from the show, Mat spotted a wide man ahead of them, sitting his saddle like a sack of suet. The horse was a leggy dun, eating ground at a steady trot. It figured that a horse thief had an eye for a good animal. Catching the sound of their hooves, Vanin looked back, but he only slowed to a walk.

ðət wɑz bæd. wən mæt sloʊd pɪps bɪsaɪd ðə dʌn, veɪnɪn spæt. "bɛst weɪdʒɝ wi ɡɑɾ ɪz wi faɪn əɹ hɔɹs ɹʌn tə dɛθ, soʊ aɪ kən tʃɹæk əɹ əfʊt fɹəm ðɛɹ," hi mʌɾɝd. "ʃiz pʊʃɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ ðən aɪ fɪɡjɝd, wɪð əɹ bæɹbæk. ɪf wi pʊʃ, wi kən meɪbi kætʃ əɹ baɪ sʌnsɛt. ɪf əɹ hɔɹs doʊn faʊndɝ əɹ daɪ, ðæts əbaʊt ðə taɪm ʃɪl meɪk kɔɹəmən."

That was bad. When Mat slowed Pips beside the dun, Vanin spat. "Best wager we got is we find her horse run to death, so I can track her afoot from there," he muttered. "She's pushing harder than I figured, with her bareback. If we push, we can maybe catch her by sunset. If her horse don't founder or die, that's about the time she'll make Coramen."

mæt tɪp bæk ɪz hɛd tə ɡlæns ət ðə sʌn, ɔlmoʊst stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd. ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ weɪ tə kʌvɝ ɪn lɛs ðən hæf ə deɪ. ɪf i tɝn bæk, hi kəd bi ə ɡʊd dɪstəns ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə dʒʊɹədɔɹ baɪ sʌnsɛt, ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð tɑm ən dʒulɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. wɪð tuɑn. wɪð ðə sintʃæn noʊɪŋ tə hʌn mæt kɔθən. ðə mæn u hæd kɪdnæp ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz kəd nɑɾ oʊn ɪnʌf lʌk tə ɡɛɾ ɔf wɪð biɪŋ meɪd dækoʊvæl. ən sʌmtaɪm təmɑɹoʊ əɹ ðə nɛks deɪ, ðeɪ wəd plæn lukə ɑn ən ɪmpəlɪŋ steɪk. lukə ən lətɛl, pɛtʃɹə ən klɛɹin ən ðə ɹɛst. ə θɪkɪɾ ʌv ɪmpəlɪŋ steɪks. ðə daɪs ɹæɾəld ən baʊnst ɪn ɪz hɛd. "wi kən meɪk ɪt," hi sɛd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs.

Mat tipped back his head to glance at the sun, almost straight overhead. It was a long way to cover in less than half a day. If he turned back, he could be a good distance the other side of Jurador by sunset, in company with Thom and Juilin and the others. With Tuon. With the Seanchan knowing to hunt Mat Cauthon. The man who had kidnapped the Daughter of the Nine Moons could not own enough luck to get off with being made da'covale. And sometime tomorrow or the next day, they would plant Luca on an impaling stake. Luca and Latelle, Petra and Clarine and the rest. A thicket of impaling stakes. The dice rattled and bounced in his head. "We can make it," he said. There was no other choice.

veɪnɪn spæt.

Vanin spat.

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn weɪ tə kʌvɝ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɡɹaʊn kwɪkli, ɑn ə hɔɹs, ɪf jə mɛn tə bi ɑn eɪ. laɪv hɔɹs ət ði ɛnd. ðeɪ wɔk ði ænəməlz fəɹ hæf ə maɪl, ðən tʃɹɑɾəd hæf ə maɪl. ðə seɪm əɾ ə kæntɝ, ðən ə ɹʌn, ən ɪt wɑz bæk tə ə wɔk. ðə sʌn bɪɡæn tə slaɪd daʊnwɝd, ən ðə daɪs spʌn.

There was only one way to cover a great deal of ground quickly, on a horse, if you meant to be on a. live horse at the end. They walked the animals for half a mile, then trotted half a mile. The same at a canter, then a run, and it was back to a walk. The sun began to slide downward, and the dice spun.

ɝaʊn spɑɹsli fɔɹəstəd hɪlz ən oʊvɝ tʃɹi-tɑpt ɹɪdʒəz. stʃɹimz ðət kəd bi kɹɔst ɪn θɹi stʃɹaɪdz, bɛɹli wɛɾɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz, ən stʃɹimz θɝɾi peɪsɪz əkɹɔs wɪð flæt bɹɪdʒəz ʌv wʊɾ əɹ səmtaɪmz stoʊn. ðə sʌn sæŋk loʊɝ ən loʊɝ, ən ðə daɪs spʌn fæstɝ ən fæstɝ. ɔlmoʊs bæk tə ði ɛlbɑɹ, ən noʊ saɪn ə ɹɛnə ɪksɛp skʌfs ɑn ðə hɑɹd dɝɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd ðət veɪnɪn pɔɪntəd tə əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ peɪntəd saɪnz.

Around sparsely forested hills and over tree-topped ridges. Streams that could be crossed in three strides, barely wetting the horses' hooves, and streams thirty paces across with flat bridges of wood or sometimes stone. The sun sank lower and lower, and the dice spun faster and faster. Almost back to the Elbar, and no sign of Renna except scuffs on the hard dirt of the road that Vanin pointed to as if they were painted signs.

"ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊs, naʊ," ðə fæt mæn mʌɾɝd. hi dɪd nɑt saʊn hæpi, ðoʊ.

"Getting close, now," the fat man muttered. He did not sound happy, though.

ðən ðeɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ə hɪl, ən ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ loʊ bɹɪdʒ əhɛd. bɪɑnd, ðə ɹoʊd twɪstəd nɔɹθ tə kɹɔs ðə nɛkst ɹɪdʒ θɹu ə sæɾəl. ðə sʌn, sɪɾɪŋ ətɑp ðə ɹɪdʒ, bleɪzd ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz.

Then they rounded a hill, and there was another low bridge ahead. Beyond, the road twisted north to cross the next ridge through a saddle. The sun, sitting atop the ridge, blazed in their eyes.

kɔɹəmən leɪ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðət ɹɪdʒ. pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæt loʊ fəɹ ʃeɪd, mæt sɝtʃt ðə ɹoʊd fəɹ ə wʊmən, fəɹ ɛniwʌn, maʊntəɾ əɹ əfʊt, ən ɪz hɑɹt sæŋk.

Coramen lay on the other side of that ridge. Pulling his hat low for shade, Mat searched the road for a woman, for anyone, mounted or afoot, and his heart sank.

veɪnɪn kɝst ən pɔɪntəd.

Vanin cursed and pointed.

ə læðɝd beɪ wɑz leɪbɝɪŋ ɪts weɪ ʌp ðə sloʊp ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, ə wʊmən fɹæntəkəli kɪkɪŋ ɪts flæŋks, ɝdʒɪŋ ɪt tə klaɪm. ɹɛnə hæd bɪn tu æŋkʃəs tə ɹitʃ ðə sintʃæn tə stɪk wɪð ðə ɹoʊd. ʃi wɑz meɪbi tu hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðɛm, ən ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn maɪlz. hɝ maʊnt wɑz ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə kəlæpsɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəd ɡɛt daʊn ən ɹʌn wɪðɪn saɪɾ ə ðə ɡæɹɪsənz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɹitʃ hɝ. ɔl ʃi hæd tə də wɑz ɹitʃ ðə kɹɛst, ənʌðɝ fɪfti fit.

A lathered bay was laboring its way up the slope on the other side of the river, a woman frantically kicking its flanks, urging it to climb. Renna had been too anxious to reach the Seanchan to stick with the road. She was maybe two hundred paces from them, and she might as well have been miles. Her mount was on the point of collapsing, but she could get down and run within sight of the garrisons before they could reach her. All she had to do was reach the crest, another fifty feet.

"maɪ lɔɹd?" hɑɹnən sɛd. hi hæɾ ən æɹoʊ nɑkt ən ɪz baʊ hæf ɹeɪzd. ɡɔɹɾɝən hɛl ðə hɛvi kɹɔsboʊ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ə θɪk pɔɪntəd boʊlt ɪn pleɪs.

"My Lord?" Harnan said. He had an arrow nocked and his bow half raised. Gorderan held the heavy crossbow to his shoulder, a thick pointed bolt in place.

mæt fɛl sʌmθɪŋ flɪkɝ ən daɪ ɪnsaɪd hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt. sʌmθɪŋ. ðə daɪs ɹoʊld laɪk θʌndɝ. "ʃut," hi sɛd. hi wɑntəd tə kloʊz ɪz aɪz. ðə kɹɔsboʊ snæpt; ðə boʊl meɪɾ ə blæk stʃɹik θɹu ði ɛɹ. ɹɛnə slæm fɔɹwɝd wən ɪt hɪɾ əɹ bæk. ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs mænədʒ tə pʊʃ hɝsɛlf ɪɹɛkt əɡɛns ðə beɪz nɛk wən hɑɹnənz æɹoʊ tʊk hɝ.

Mat felt something flicker and die inside him. He did not know what. Something. The dice rolled like thunder. "Shoot," he said. He wanted to close his eyes. The crossbow snapped; the bolt made a black streak through the air. Renna slammed forward when it hit her back. She had almost managed to push herself erect against the bay's neck when Harnan's arrow took her.

sloʊli, ʃi tɑpəl fɹəm ðə hɔɹs, slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp, ɹoʊlɪŋ, baʊnsɪŋ ɔf sæplɪŋz, tʌmbəlɪŋ fæstɝ ən fæstɝ əntɪl ʃi splæʃt ɪndə ðə stʃɹim. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi floʊɾəd feɪsdaʊn əɡɛns ðə bæŋk, ən ðən ðə kɝən kɑɾ əɹ ən pʊld əɹ əweɪ, skɝts bɪloʊɪŋ ʌp ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ. sloʊli ʃi dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹd ði ɛlbɑɹ. meɪbi, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ʃi wəd ɹitʃ ðə si. ən ðət meɪd θɹi. ɪt hɑɹdli sim tə mæɾɝ ðət ðə daɪs hæd stɑpt. ðət meɪd θɹi. nɛvɝ əɡɛn, hi θɔɾ əz ɹɛnə floʊɾəd aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ɝaʊn ə bɛnd. aɪaɪaɪ daɪ fəɹ ɪt, nɛvɝ əɡɛn. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt pɹɛs, ɹaɪɾɪŋ bæk istwɝd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪnt, ən mæt fɛl tu boʊn-wɪɹi. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt stɑp, ðoʊ, ɪksɛp tə bɹið ən wɔɾɝ ðə hɔɹsəz. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə tɔk. ɪt wɑz ðə smɔl aʊɝz ə ðə naɪt wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt dʒʊɹədɔɹ, ðə taʊn ə dɑɹk mæs wɪð ðə ɡeɪts ʃʌt taɪt. klaʊdz kʌvɝd ðə mun. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðə kænvəs wɔlz ə lukəz ʃoʊ wɝ stɪl ɪn pleɪs dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə taʊn. wɪð ə pɛɹ ə bʌlki mɛn ɹæpt ɪn blæŋkəts snɔɹɪŋ əwɛɹ bɪniθ ðə bɪɡ bænɝ əz ðeɪ ɡɑɹɾəd ði ɛntʃɹəns. ivən fɹəm ðə ɹoʊd, ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðət wæɡənz ən tɛns fɪl ðə speɪs bɪhaɪn ðə wɔl.

Slowly, she toppled from the horse, sliding down the slope, rolling, bouncing off saplings, tumbling faster and faster until she splashed into the stream. For a moment, she floated facedown against the bank, and then the current caught her and pulled her away, skirts billowing up on the water. Slowly she drifted toward the Elbar. Maybe, eventually, she would reach the sea. And that made three. It hardly seemed to matter that the dice had stopped. That made three. Never again, he thought as Renna floated out of sight around a bend. III die for it, never again. They did not press, riding back eastward. There was no point, and Mat felt too bone-weary. They did not stop, though, except to breathe and water the horses. No one wanted to talk. It was the small hours of the night when they reached Jurador, the town a dark mass with the gates shut tight. Clouds covered the moon. Surprisingly, the canvas walls of Luca's show were still in place just beyond the town. With a pair of bulky men wrapped in blankets snoring aware beneath the big banner as they guarded the entrance. Even from the road, in the dark, it was plain that wagons and tents filled the space behind the wall.

"æt list aɪ kən tɛl lukə hi dʌzn əv tə ɹʌn æftɝ ɔl," mæt sɛd wɛɹəli, tɝnɪŋ pɪps təwɔɹd ðə bænɝ. "meɪbi hɪl ɡɪv əs ə pleɪs tə slip ə fju aʊɝz." fəɹ ɔl ðə ɡoʊld i hæd lɛft, lukə ʃəd ɡɪv əm ɪz oʊn wæɡən, bʌt noʊɪŋ ðə mæn, mæt hæd hoʊps fəɹ klin stʃɹɔ sʌmwɛɹ. təmɑɹoʊ, hi wəd sɛɾ aʊt tə faɪn tɑm ən ði ʌðɝz. ən tuɑn. təmɑɹoʊ, wən i hæd ɹɛstəd.

"At least I can tell Luca he doesn't have to run after all," Mat said wearily, turning Pips toward the banner. "Maybe he'll give us a place to sleep a few hours." For all the gold he had left, Luca should give them his own wagon, but knowing the man, Mat had hopes for clean straw somewhere. Tomorrow, he would set out to find Thom and the others. And Tuon. Tomorrow, when he had rested.

ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ʃɑk weɪɾəd ɪnsaɪd lukəz hjudʒ wæɡən. ɪt tʃɹuli wɑz ɹumi ɪnsaɪd, ət lis fəɹ ə wæɡən, wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ teɪbəl sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ən speɪs tə wɔk ɝaʊn ɪt. teɪbəl, kʌbɝdz ən ʃɛlvz ɔl wɝ pɑlɪʃt tɪl ðeɪ ɡloʊd. tuɑn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹ  -  lukə wəɾ əv ə tʃɛɹ, ən ɡɪldɪd, wən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls meɪd də wɪð stulz!  -  wɪð sɪlutʃə stændɪŋ əɾ əɹ bæk. ə bimɪŋ lukə wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ lətɛl ɔfɝ tuɑn ə pleɪɾ ə stimɪŋ peɪstʃɹiz, wɪtʃ ðə dɑɹk lɪɾəl wʊmən wɑz ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi wəɾ æktʃəli  it sʌmθɪŋ ðət lukəz waɪf hæd kʊkt. tuɑn ʃoʊd noʊ sɝpɹaɪz əɾ ɔl ət mæt wɔkɪŋ ɪndə ðə wæɡən. "ɪz ʃi kæptʃɝd, əɹ dɛd?" ʃi sɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ə peɪstʃɹi wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz kɝvd ɪn ðət kjʊɹiəsli ɡɹeɪsfəl weɪ. "dɛd," hi sɛd flætli. "lukə, wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt -  " "aɪ fɝbɪɾ ɪt, tɔɪ!" tuɑn snæpt, pɔɪntɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɾ ɪm ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ fɝbɪd jə tə mɔɹn ə tʃɹeɪɾɝ!" hɝ vɔɪs sɔfənd, slaɪtli, bʌɾ ɪt ɹɪmeɪn fɝm. "ʃi ɝn dɛθ baɪ bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ən wʊɾə əv bɪtʃɹeɪd jə əz izəli. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪtʃɹeɪ ju. wʌt jə dɪd wɑz dʒʌstəs, ən aɪ neɪm ɪt soʊ." hɝ toʊn sɛd ðəɾ ɪf ʃi neɪmd ə θɪŋ, ðən ɪt wɑz wɛl ən tʃɹuli neɪmd.

A greater shock waited inside Luca's huge wagon. It truly was roomy inside, at least for a wagon, with a narrow table sitting in the middle and space to walk around it. Table, cupboards and shelves all were polished till they glowed. Tuon was sitting in a gilded chair  -  Luca would have a chair, and gilded, when everybody else made do with stools!  -  with Selucia standing at her back. A beaming Luca was watching Latelle offer Tuon a plate of steaming pastries, which the dark little woman was examining as if she would actually eat something that Luca's wife had cooked. Tuon showed no surprise at all at Mat walking into the wagon. "Is she captured, or dead?" she said, picking up a pastry with her fingers curved in that curiously graceful way. "Dead," he said flatly. "Luca, what in the Light -  " "I forbid it, Toy!" Tuon snapped, pointing a finger at him sharply. "I forbid you to mourn a traitor!" Her voice softened, slightly, but it remained firm. "She earned death by betraying the Empire, and she would have betrayed you as easily. She was trying to betray you. What you did was justice, and I name it so." Her tone said that if she named a thing, then it was well and truly named.

mæt skwizd ɪz aɪz ʃʌt fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ɪz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls stɪl hɪɹ, tu?" hi dɪmændəd.

Mat squeezed his eyes shut for a moment. "Is everyone else still here, too?" he demanded.

"ʌv kɔɹs," lukə sɛd, stɪl smaɪlɪŋ laɪk ə bʊlɡus ful. "ðə leɪɾi - ðə haɪ leɪɾi; fɝɡɪv mi, haɪ leɪɾi." hi baʊd dipli. "ʃi tɔk tə mɛɹɪlɪn ən sændɑɹ, ænd. . . . wɛl, jə si haʊ ɪt wɑz. ə vɛɹi pɝsweɪsɪv wʊmən, ðə leɪɾi. ðə haɪ leɪɾi. kɔθən, əbaʊt maɪ ɡoʊld. jə sɛd ðeɪ wɝ tə hæn ɪɾ oʊvɝ, bʌt mɛɹɪlɪn sɛd hid slɪt maɪ θɹoʊt fɝst, ən sændɑɹ θɹɛɾənd tə kɹæk maɪ hɛd, ænd. .

"Of course," Luca said, still smiling like a bullgoose fool. "The Lady - the High Lady; forgive me, High Lady." He bowed deeply. "She talked to Merrilin and Sandar, and. . . . Well, you see how it was. A very persuasive woman, the Lady. The High Lady. Cauthon, about my gold. You said they were to hand it over, but Merrilin said he'd slit my throat first, and Sandar threatened to crack my head, and. .

. ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf ʌndɝ mæts stɛɹ, ðən sʌɾənli bɹaɪɾənd əɡɛn. "lʊk wʌt ðə leɪɾi ɡeɪv mi!" snætʃɪŋ oʊpən wʌn ə ðə kʌbɝdz, hi pʊld aʊɾ ə foʊldəd peɪpɝ ðəɾ i hɛld ɹɛvɝənli ɪn boʊθ hænz.

. ." He trailed off under Mat's stare, then suddenly brightened again. "Look what the Lady gave me!" Snatching open one of the cupboards, he pulled out a folded paper that he held reverently in both hands.

ɪt wɑz θɪk peɪpɝ, ən waɪɾ əz snoʊ; ɪkspɛnsɪv. "ə wɔɹənt. nɑt sild, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt saɪnd. vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ən mæɡnɪfəsən dɪspleɪ ʌv mɑɹvəlz ən wʌndɝz ɪz naʊ ʌndɝ ðə pɝsənəl pɹətɛkʃən ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn æθeɪɪm kɔɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɪl noʊ hu ðəɾ ɪz, ʌv kɔɹs. aɪ kəd ɡoʊ tə sintʃæn. aɪ kəd pʊɾ ɑn maɪ ʃoʊ fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs! meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ," hi æɾəd heɪstəli, wɪð ənʌðɝ baʊ tə tuɑn.

It was thick paper, and white as snow; expensive. "A warrant. Not sealed, of course, but signed. Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvels and Wonders is now under the personal protection of the High Lady Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag. Everyone will know who that is, of course. I could go to Seanchan. I could put on my show for the Empress! May she live forever," he added hastily, with another bow to Tuon.

fəɹ nʌθɪŋ, mæt θɔt blikli. hi sæŋk daʊn ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɛdz wɪð ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz, ɝnɪŋ ə vɛɹi pɔɪntəd lʊk fɹəm lətɛl. laɪkli oʊnli tuɑnz pɹɛzəns kɛpt əɹ fɹəm klaʊɾɪŋ hɪm!

For nothing, Mat thought bleakly. He sank down on one of the beds with his elbows on his knees, earning a very pointed look from Latelle. Likely only Tuon's presence kept her from clouting him!

tuɑn ɹeɪzd ə pɝɛmptɝi hænd, ə blæk pɔɹsələn dɑl bʌɾ ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə kwin dɪspaɪt ðə ʃæbi tu-lɑɹdʒ dʒɹɛs. "ju ɑɹ nɑt tə juz ðəɾ ɪksɛpt ət nid, mæstɝ lukə. ɡɹeɪt nid!" "ʌv kɔɹs, haɪ leɪɾi; ʌv kɔɹs." lukə bɑbd baʊz əz ɪf i maɪt bi kɪsɪŋ ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz ɛni mɪnət. ɔl fəɹ blʌɾi nʌθɪŋ!

Tuon raised a peremptory hand, a black porcelain doll but every inch a queen despite the shabby too-large dress. "You are not to use that except at need, Master Luca. Great need!" "Of course, High Lady; of course." Luca bobbed bows as if he might be kissing the floorboards any minute. All for bloody nothing!

"aɪ dɪd meɪk spəsɪfɪk mɛnʃən ə hu ɪz nɑɾ ʌndɝ maɪ pɹətɛkʃən, tɔɪ." tuɑn tʊk ə baɪɾ ə peɪstʃɹi ən dɛləkətli bɹʌʃt ə kɹʌm fɹəm əɹ lɪp wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ. "kæn jə ɡɛs huz neɪm hɛdz ðət lɪst?" ʃi smaɪld. nɑɾ ə məlɪʃəs smaɪl. ənʌðɝ ə ðoʊz smaɪlz fəɹ hɝsɛlf, əmjuzmən əɹ dɪlaɪɾ ɪn sʌmθɪŋ i kəd nɑt si. sʌɾənli, hi noʊɾəst sʌmθɪŋ. ðət lɪɾəl klʌstɝ ə sɪlk ɹoʊzbʊdz i hæd ɡɪvən əɹ wɑz pɪn tə hɝ ʃoʊldɝ. dɪspaɪt hɪmsɛlf, mæt bɪɡæn tə læf. hi θɹu hɪz hæt daʊn ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən læft. wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɔl ɪz ɛfɝts, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðɪs wʊmən əɾ ɔl! nɑɾ ə bɪt! hi læft əntɪl ɪz ɹɪbz hɝt.

"I did make specific mention of who is not under my protection, Toy." Tuon took a bite of pastry and delicately brushed a crumb from her lip with a finger. "Can you guess whose name heads that list?" She smiled. Not a malicious smile. Another of those smiles for herself, amusement or delight in something he could not see. Suddenly, he noticed something. That little cluster of silk rosebuds he had given her was pinned to her shoulder. Despite himself, Mat began to laugh. He threw his hat down on the floor and laughed. With everything, all his efforts, he did not know this woman at all! Not a bit! He laughed until his ribs hurt.

tʃæptɝ θɝɾi

CHAPTER 30

wʌt ði oʊθ ɹɑd kən də ðə sʌn sæɾ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən, pɝfəkli sɪləuɛɾɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, bʌt ðə koʊld ə ðə pɹiviəs naɪt sim tə bi dipənɪŋ, ən dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz mɑɹtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ θɹɛɾənd ə snoʊfɔl. wɪntɝ wɑz dɪmɪnɪʃɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪt hæd klʌŋ pæst wən spɹɪŋ ʃəɾ əv bɪɡʌn, lusənɪŋ ɪts hoʊl fɪtfəli. ðə nɔɪzɪz ə mɔɹnɪŋ pɛnətʃɹeɪɾəd ɛɡwinz tɛnt, aɪsəleɪɾəd əz ɪt wɑz fɹəm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪt. ðə kæmp sim tə vaɪbɹeɪt. leɪbɝɝz wəd bi bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə wɛlz, ən ɛkstʃɹə mɛʒɝz ə faɪɝwʊɾ ən tʃɑɹkoʊl ɪn kɑɹts. sɝvɪŋ wɪmən wəd bi fɛtʃɪŋ sɪstɝz' bɹɛkfəsts, ən nɑvəsɪz ɪn ðə sɛkən sɪɾɪŋ skɝiɪŋ tə ðɛɹz, ðoʊz ɪn ðə fɝst ən θɝd tə klæsəz. ɪt wɑz ə moʊmɛntəs deɪ, ðoʊ nʌn ə ðɛm nu ɪt. laɪkli, tədeɪ wəd si ən ɛn tə ðə spjʊɹiəs nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz ðət wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn dɛɹn, əɾ ə teɪbəl ʌndɝ ə pəvɪljən ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. spjʊɹiəs ɑn boʊθ saɪdz. ɪleɪɾəz ɹeɪɾɝz kəntɪnjud tə stʃɹaɪk wɪð ɪmpjunɪɾi ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, tədeɪ wəd bi ðə læs miɾɪŋ fəɹ səm taɪm.

What the Oath Rod Can Do The sun sat on the horizon, perfectly silhouetting the White Tower in the distance, but the cold of the previous night seemed to be deepening, and dark gray clouds marching across the sky threatened a snowfall. Winter was diminishing, yet it had clung past when spring should have begun, loosening its hold fitfully. The noises of morning penetrated Egwene's tent, isolated as it was from everything around it. The camp seemed to vibrate. Laborers would be bringing in water from the wells, and extra measures of firewood and charcoal in carts. Serving women would be fetching sisters' breakfasts, and novices in the second sitting scurrying to theirs, those in the first and third to classes. It was a momentous day, though none of them knew it. Likely, today would see an end to the spurious negotiations that were going on in Darein, at a table under a pavilion at the foot of the bridge to Tar Valon. Spurious on both sides. Elaida's raiders continued to strike with impunity on the other side of the river. In any case, today would be the last meeting for some time.

piɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ oʊn bɹɛkfəst, ɛɡwin saɪɾ ən pɪkt ə taɪni blæk flɛk aʊɾ ə ðə stimɪŋ pɔɹədʒ, waɪpɪŋ ɪt fɹəm əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ə lɪnən næpkɪn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ kloʊsli ɪnʌf tə bi ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə wivəl. ɪf jə kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ, ðən jə wɝid lɛs əbaʊt wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə boʊl. ʃi pʊɾ ə spunfʊl ɪndə hɝ maʊθ ən tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə swit slɪvɝz ə dʒɹaɪɾ eɪpɹəkɑt ðət tʃɛsə hæd blɛndəɾ ɪn. dɪd sʌmθɪŋ kɹæk ʌndɝ əɹ tiθ? "ɪɾ ɔl fidz ðə bɛli, maɪ mʌðɝ juz tə seɪ, soʊ peɪ ɪt noʊ maɪnd," tʃɛsə mɝmɝɾ əz ɪf tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ðət wɑz haʊ ʃi ɡeɪv ɛɡwin ædvaɪs, wɪθaʊt stʃɹeɪɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə laɪn bɪtwin mɪstʃɹəs ən meɪd. ət list, ʃi ɡeɪv ædvaɪs wən hɑlimə wɑz nɑt pɹɛzənt, ən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən hæd lɛft ɝli ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. tʃɛsə wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn ə ðə kloʊðɪŋ tʃɛsts, ɪn keɪs ɛɡwin wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ əɹ niɾəd ən ɛɹən ɹʌn, bʌt naʊ ən ðən əɹ aɪz stʃɹeɪd tə ðə paɪl ʌv ɡɑɹməns ðət wɝ tə ɡoʊ ðə wɑʃwɪmən tədeɪ. ʃi nɛvɝ maɪndəd dɑɹnɪŋ əɹ mɛndɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɡwin, bʌɾ ɪn əɹ bʊk, sɔɹɾɪŋ lɔnʒɹi wʊɾə bɪn stɛpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðət laɪn.

Peering at her own breakfast, Egwene sighed and picked a tiny black fleck out of the steaming porridge, wiping it from her fingers on a linen napkin without looking closely enough to be sure that it was a weevil. If you could not be sure, then you worried less about what remained in the bowl. She put a spoonful into her mouth and tried to concentrate on the sweet slivers of dried apricot that Chesa had blended in. Did something crack under her teeth? "It all feeds the belly, my mother used to say, so pay it no mind," Chesa murmured as if talking to herself. That was how she gave Egwene advice, without straying across the line between mistress and maid. At least, she gave advice when Halima was not present, and the other woman had left early this morning. Chesa was sitting on one of the clothing chests, in case Egwene wanted something or needed an errand run, but now and then her eyes strayed to the pile of garments that were to go the washwomen today. She never minded darning or mending in front of Egwene, but in her book, sorting laundry would have been stepping over that line.
