smuðɪŋ ðə ɡɹɪmɑs fɹəm əɹ feɪs, ɛɡwin wɑz əbaʊt tə tɛl ðə wʊmən tə ɡoʊ ɡɛɾ əɹ oʊn bɹɛkfəst - tʃɛsə kənsɪɾɝd iɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛɡwin fɪnɪʃt ənʌðɝ tʃɹænzɡɹɛʃən - bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, naɪsaʊ pʊʃt ɪndə ðə tɛnt, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə ɡloʊ ɑfseɪaɪdɑɹ. əz ði ɛntʃɹi flæps fɛl, ɛɡwin kɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə sɑɹɪn, naɪsaʊz bɔld, blæk-bɪɹɾəd stʌmp ʌv ə wɔɹɾɝ, weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd.

Smoothing the grimace from her face, Egwene was about to tell the woman to go get her own breakfast - Chesa considered eating before Egwene finished another transgression - but before she could open her mouth, Nisao pushed into the tent, surrounded by the glow ofsaidar. As the entry flaps fell, Egwene caught a glimpse of Sarin, Nisao's bald, black-bearded stump of a Warder, waiting outside.

ðə smɔl sɪstɝz kaʊl wɑz daʊn, kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒd ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz soʊ ðə jɛloʊ vɛlvət laɪnɪŋ ʃoʊd, jɛt ʃi wɑz klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ kloʊk əz ðoʊ ʃi fɛl ðə koʊld ɪntɛnsli. ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌst ɡeɪv tʃɛsə ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. tʃɛsə weɪɾəd fəɹ ɛɡwinz nɑd, ɡæðɝɾ əɹ oʊn kloʊk ən skɝiɾ aʊt. ʃi maɪt nɑt bi eɪbəl tə si ðə laɪɾ ə ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ʃi nu wən ɛɡwin wɑntəd pɹaɪvəsi.

The small sister's cowl was down, carefully arranged on her shoulders so the yellow velvet lining showed, yet she was clutching her cloak as though she felt the cold intensely. She said nothing, just gave Chesa a sharp look. Chesa waited for Egwene's nod, gathered her own cloak and scurried out. She might not be able to see the light of the Power, but she knew when Egwene wanted privacy.

"kɛɹən stæŋ ɪz dɛd," naɪsaʊ sɛd wɪθaʊt pɹiæmbəl. hɝ feɪs wɑz smuð, hɝ vɔɪs stɛɾi, ən tʃɪl. ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛɡwin fil tɔl, ʃi stʊɾ əz ðoʊ stʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ ən ɛkstʃɹə ɪntʃ. naɪsaʊ dɪd nɑt juʒəwəli də ðæt. "sɛvən sɪstɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tɛstəd fəɹ ɹɛzənəns bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡɑt ðɛɹ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ daʊt ʃi wɑz kɪl juzɪŋ seɪɾɪn. hɝ nɛk wɑz bɹoʊkən. ʃæɾɝd. əz ɪf əɹ hɛd hæd bɪn ɹɛntʃt ɝaʊn fʊl sɝkəl. ət list ɪt wɑz kwɪk." naɪsaʊ dʒɹu ə dip, ənstɛɾi bɹɛθ, ðən ɹilaɪzd wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ən pʊl hɝsɛlf ʌp ivən stʃɹeɪɾɝ. "hɝ wɔɹɾɝ ɪz pɹaɪm fəɹ mɝɾɝ.

"Kairen Stang is dead," Nisao said without preamble. Her face was smooth, her voice steady, and chill. Short enough to make Egwene feel tall, she stood as though straining for an extra inch. Nisao did not usually do that. "Seven sisters had already tested for resonance before I got there. There is no doubt she was killed using saidin. Her neck was broken. Shattered. As if her head had been wrenched around full circle. At least it was quick." Nisao drew a deep, unsteady breath, then realized what she had done and pulled herself up even straighter. "Her Warder is primed for murder.

sʌmwʌn ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɝbəl kənkɑkʃən tə pʊɾ ɪm tə slip, bʌt hi, wɪl bi tʃɹʌbəl tə hændəl wʌns i weɪks." ʃi dɪd nɑt pʊt ðə juʒəwəl dɪsmɪsɪv jɛloʊ twɪst ɑn ðə mɛnʃən ə ɝbz, ə mɛʒɝ ə hɝ əpsɛt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ kɑm əɹ feɪs wɑz.

Someone gave him an herbal concoction to put him to sleep, but he, will be trouble to handle once he wakes." She did not put the usual dismissive Yellow twist on the mention of herbs, a measure of her upset no matter how calm her face was.

ɛɡwin sɛɾ əɹ spun daʊn ɑn ðə taɪni teɪbəl ən lin bæk. sʌɾənli, hɝ tʃɛɹ dɪd nɑt fil kʌmftəɹbəl ɛnimɔɹ. naʊ ðə nɛks bɛst æftɝ lin wɑz boʊd kɔθən. ə nɑvəs. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌɾ ɛls boʊd wɑz. wɪð ði ɛkstʃɹə deɪz ə pɹæktəs, boʊd kəd də ðə wɝk ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz kɛɹən kəd hæv. ɔlmoʊst. ʃi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðæt, ðoʊ. naɪsaʊ nu səm sikɹəts, bʌt nɑɾ ɔl. "æneɪjə, ən naʊ kɛɹən. boʊθ blu ədʒɑ. dʒju noʊ ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ lɪŋk bɪtwin ðɛm?" naɪsaʊ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "æneɪjə hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fɪfti əɹ sɪksti jɪɹz wən kɛɹən keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ, əz aɪ ɹikɔl. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd mjutʃəwəl əkweɪntənsɪz. aɪ dʒʌs doʊnt noʊ, mʌðɝ." naʊ ʃi saʊndəd taɪɝd, ən əɹ ʃoʊldɝz slʌmpt ə lɪɾəl. hɝ kwaɪəɾ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪʃən ɪndə æneɪjəz dɛθ hæd ɡɑɾən noʊwɛɹ, ən ʃi hæd tə bi əwɛɹ ɛɡwin wɑz gɑnə æd kɛɹən.

Egwene set her spoon down on the tiny table and leaned back. Suddenly, her chair did not feel comfortable anymore. Now the next best after Leane was Bode Cauthon. A novice. She tried not to think of what else Bode was. With the extra days of practice, Bode could do the work almost as well as Kairen could have. Almost. She did not mention that, though. Nisao knew some secrets, but not all. "Anaiya, and now Kairen. Both Blue Ajah. Do you know of any other link between them?" Nisao shook her head. "Anaiya had been Aes Sedai fifty or sixty years when Kairen came to the Tower, as I recall. Perhaps they had mutual acquaintances. I just don't know, Mother." Now she sounded tired, and her shoulders slumped a little. Her quiet investigation into Anaiya's death had gotten nowhere, and she had to be aware Egwene was going to add Kairen.

"faɪn aʊt," ɛɡwin ɔɹɾɝd. "dɪskɹitli." ðɪs sɛkən mɝɾɝ wəd kɑz ɪnʌf ɹʌkʃən wɪθaʊɾ əɹ æɾɪŋ tə ɪt. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi stʌɾid ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. naɪsaʊ maɪt meɪk ɪkskjuzɪz æftɝ ðə fækt, əɹ kleɪm ʃi hæd bɪn daʊtfəl fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, bʌɾ əntɪl ðɛn, ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mɑɾəl ə jɛloʊ ədʒɑ sɛlf-əʃʊɹəns ən æbsəlut sɝɾənti. nɑt naʊ, haʊɛvɝ. "ɑɹ mɛni sɪstɝz wɔkɪŋ əbaʊt hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ?"

"Find out," Egwene ordered. "Discreetly." This second murder would cause enough ruction without her adding to it. For a moment, she studied the other woman. Nisao might make excuses after the fact, or claim she had been doubtful from the start, but until then, she was always a model of Yellow Ajah self-assurance and absolute certainty. Not now, however. "Are many sisters walking about holding saidar?"

"aɪv noʊɾəst sɛvɹəl, mʌðɝ," naɪsaʊ sɛd stɪfli. hɝ tʃɪn ɹoʊz wɪðɪn ə fɹækʃən ə dɪfaɪəns.

"I've noticed several, Mother," Nisao said stiffly. Her chin rose within a fraction of defiance.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðoʊ, ðə ɡloʊ ɝaʊn əɹ wɪŋkt aʊt. ʃi pʊld əɹ kloʊk taɪɾɝ, əz ɪf ʃi hæd sʌɾənli lɔst wɔɹmθ. "aɪ daʊɾ ɪt wʊɾə dʌn kɛɹən ɛni ɡʊd. hɝ dɛθ wɑz tu sʌɾən. bʌɾ ɪt meɪks ə pɝsən fil . . . seɪfɝ."

After a moment, though, the glow around her winked out. She pulled her cloak tighter, as if she had suddenly lost warmth. "I doubt it would have done Kairen any good. Her death was too sudden. But it makes a person feel . . . safer."

æftɝ ðə smɔl wʊmən lɛft, ɛɡwin sæt stɝɪŋ əɹ pɔɹədʒ wɪð əɹ spun. ʃi dɪd nɑt si ɛni mɔɹ dɑɹk flɛks, bʌɾ əɹ æpətaɪt wɑz ɡɔn. faɪnəli, ʃi ɹoʊz ən sɛɾəld ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, ðən swʌŋ əɹ kloʊk ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz. tədeɪ ʌv ɔl deɪz, ʃi wəd nɑt sɪt maɪɹɾ ɪn ɡlum.

After the small woman left, Egwene sat stirring her porridge with her spoon. She did not see any more dark flecks, but her appetite was gone. Finally, she rose and settled the seven-striped stole around her neck, then swung her cloak onto her shoulders. Today of all days, she would not sit mired in gloom.

tədeɪ ʌv ɔl deɪz, ʃi mʌs fɑloʊ hɝ ɹutin ɪɡzækli.

Today of all days, she must follow her routine exactly.

aʊtsaɪd, haɪ-wil kɑɹts tʃɹʌndəld əlɔŋ ðə fɹoʊzən ɹʌts ə ðə kæmp stʃɹits, fɪld wɪð bɪɡ wɔɾɝ bæɹəlz əɹ paɪlz ə splɪt faɪɝwʊɾ ən sæks ə tʃɑɹkoʊl, ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz ən ðə fɛloʊz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn əlaɪk ɛnvɛləpt ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks əɡɛns ðə koʊld. əz juʒəwəl, fæmliz ə nɑvəsɪz hɝiɾ əlɔŋ ðə wʊɾən wɔkweɪz, juʒəwəli mænɪdʒɪŋ tə meɪk ðɛɹ kɝɾəsiz tə pæsɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ. feɪljɝ ɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛks tə ə sɪstɝ kəɾ ɝn ə swɪtʃɪŋ, bʌt soʊ kəd tɑɹɾinəs, ən titʃɝz wɝ dʒɛnɝəli lɛs tɑlɝən ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ɪn pæsɪŋ, hu ət lis maɪt meɪk əlaʊənsɪz fəɹ waɪ ə nɑvəs wɛn ɹʌʃɪŋ baɪ. ðə waɪt-klæd wɪmən stɪl lɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ət saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹaɪp stoʊl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɛɡwinz kaʊl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ əɹ mud bi saʊɝd, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz, baɪ nɑvəsɪz kɝtsiɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹit, slɪpɪŋ ən slaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði aɪs-hɑɹd ɡɹaʊn ən səmtaɪmz ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ kʌzənz kəd ɡɹæb ðɛm. "kʌzən" wɑz wʌt mɛmbɝz ə ðə seɪm fæmli hæd teɪkən tə kɔlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən sʌmhaʊ ðət sim tə taɪ ðɛm kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ, əz ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ ɹɪleɪɾɪd, ən kloʊs kʌzənz ət ðæt. wʌd saʊɝ əɹ mud wɝ ðə fju ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃi sɔ aʊɾ ən əbaʊt, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔkweɪz θɹu ɹɪpəlz ə kɝtsiz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən əɹ soʊ bɪtwin əɹ tɛn ən ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi, bʌt θɹi aʊɾ ʌv ɛvɹi fɔɹ wɝ ɹæpt ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə paʊɝ əz wɛl əz kloʊks. ðeɪ wɔkt ɪn pɛɹz mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt, fɑloʊd baɪ ɛni wɔɹɾɝz ðeɪ hæd. ðeɪ simd wɑtʃfəl, tu, ɛnvɛləpt ɪn seɪaɪdɑɹ əɹ nɑt, kaʊlz swɪvəlɪŋ kɑnstənli əz ðeɪ skæn ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt. ɪt maɪndəɾ əɹ ə ðə taɪm spɑɾəd fivɝ hæd stʃɹʌk ɛmənz fild, ən ɛvɹiwʌn wɔkt ɝaʊn klʌtʃɪŋ bɹændi-soʊk hæŋkɝtʃəfs tə ðɛɹ noʊzɪz - dɔɹæl bæɹən, ðə wɪzdəm ðɛn, hæd sɛd ðət wəd hɛlp steɪv ɪɾ ɔf - klʌtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ hæŋkɝtʃəfs ən wɑtʃɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ tə si hu wəd bi ðə nɛks tə bɹeɪk aʊɾ ɪn spɑts ən fɔl oʊvɝ.

Outside, high-wheeled carts trundled along the frozen ruts of the camp streets, filled with big water barrels or piles of split firewood and sacks of charcoal, the drivers and the fellows riding behind alike enveloped in their cloaks against the cold. As usual, families of novices hurried along the wooden walkways, usually managing to make their courtesies to passing Aes Sedai without slowing. Failure in the proper respects to a sister could earn a switching, but so could tardiness, and teachers were generally less tolerant than Aes Sedai encountered in passing, who at least might make allowances for why a novice went rushing by. The white-clad women still leapt out of the way at sight of the striped stole hanging from Egwene's cowl, of course, but she refused to let her mood be soured, any more than it already was, by novices curtsying in the street, slipping and sliding on the ice-hard ground and sometimes almost falling on their faces before their cousins could grab them. "Cousin" was what members of the same family had taken to calling one another, and somehow that seemed to tie them closer together, as if they really were related, and close cousins at that. What did sour her mood were the few Aes Sedai she saw out and about, gliding along the walkways through ripples of curtsies. There were no more than a dozen or so between her tent and the Amyrlin's study, but three out of every four were wrapped in the light of the Power as well as cloaks. They walked in pairs more often than not, followed by any Warders they had. They seemed watchful, too, enveloped in saidar or not, cowls swiveling constantly as they scanned everyone in sight. It minded her of the time spotted fever had struck Emond's Field, and everyone walked around clutching brandy-soaked handkerchiefs to their noses - Doral Barran, the Wisdom then, had said that would help stave it off - clutching their handkerchiefs and watching one another to see who would be the next to break out in spots and fall over.

ɪlɛvən pipəl daɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə fivɝ ɹæn ɪts kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə mʌnθ æftɝ ðə læs pɝsən fɛl sɪk bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə pʊt ðoʊz hæŋkɝtʃəfs əweɪ. fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ʃi hæɾ əsoʊsieɪɾəd ðə smɛl ə bɹændi wɪð fɪɹ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst smɛl ɪt naʊ. tu sɪstɝz hæd bɪn mɝɾɝd ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst, baɪ ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən əpɛɹənli biɪŋ eɪbəl tə kʌm ən ɡoʊ əz i tʃoʊz. fɪɹ wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fæstɝ ðən spɑɾəd fivɝ ɛvɝ kʊd.

Eleven people died before the fever ran its course, but it was a month after the last person fell sick before everyone was willing to put those handkerchiefs away. For a long time, she had associated the smell of brandy with fear. She could almost smell it now. Two sisters had been murdered in their midst, by a man who could channel, not to mention apparently being able to come and go as he chose. Fear was running through the Aes Sedai faster than spotted fever ever could.

ðə tɛnt ʃi juzd əz ə stʌɾi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi wɔɹm wən ʃi, ɝaɪvd, ðə bɹeɪziɝ ɡɪvɪŋ ɔf ə sɛn ə ɹoʊzɪz. ðə mɪɹɝd stændlæmps ən teɪbəl-læmp wɝ lɪt. hɝ ɹutin wɑz wɛl noʊn. hæŋɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɑn ðə kloʊk ɹæk ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ʃi tʊk əɹ sit bɪhaɪn ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, ɔɾəmætɪkli kætʃɪŋ ði ənstɛɾi tʃɛɹ lɛɡ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə foʊld. ɔl ʃi hæd tə də wɑz fɑloʊ ɹutin. təmɑɹoʊ, ʃi kəɾ ənaʊns wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn. hɝ fɝs vɪzəɾɝ wɑz ə ʃɑk, pɝhæps ðə læst wʊmən ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə wɔk ɪndə ðə tɛnt. θiədʒɹɪn wɑz ə wɪləwi, æpəlɪtʃik bɹaʊn, ə kɑpɝ-skɪn dəmɑni wɪð ə stʌbɝn sɛt tə hɝ maʊθ. wʌns, ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə smaɪl. ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə wɔɹn kɑɹpəts, kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə fɹɪnʒ ə hɝ ʃɔl tə bɹʌʃ ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. əz ʃi meɪɾ ə vɛɹi fɔɹməl kɝtsi, ɛɡwin ɪkstɛndəɾ əɹ lɛf hæn soʊ ðə wʊmən kəd kɪs əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. fɔɹmæləɾi mʌs bi mɛt wɪð fɔɹmæləɾi. "ɹoʊmændə wɪʃɪz tə noʊ ɪf ʃi kən mit wɪð jə tədeɪ, mʌðɝ," ðə slɛndɝ bɹaʊn sɛd. sɔfli, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə stʌbɝnnəs bɛɹiɾ ɪn əɹ toʊn, tu.

The tent she used as a study was already warm when she, arrived, the brazier giving off a scent of roses. The mirrored standlamps and table-lamp were lit. Her routine was well known. Hanging her cloak on the cloak rack in the corner, she took her seat behind the writing table, automatically catching the unsteady chair leg that always tried to fold. All she had to do was follow routine. Tomorrow, she could announce what had been done. Her first visitor was a shock, perhaps the last woman she expected to walk into the tent. Theodrin was a willowy, applecheeked Brown, a copper-skinned Domani with a stubborn set to her mouth. Once, she had always looked ready to smile. She glided across the worn carpets, close enough for the fringe of her shawl to brush the writing table. As she made a very formal curtsy, Egwene extended her left hand so the woman could kiss her Great Serpent ring. Formality must be met with formality. "Romanda wishes to know if she can meet with you today, Mother," the slender Brown said. Softly, but there was a stubbornness buried in her tone, too.

"tɛl hɝ, əɾ ɛni taɪm ʃi tʃuzəz, dɔɾɝ," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd kɛɹfəli. θiədʒɹɪn ɔfɝɾ ənʌðɝ kɝtsi wɪθaʊt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

"Tell her, at any time she chooses, Daughter," Egwene replied carefully. Theodrin offered another curtsy without changing expression.

əz ðə bɹaʊn muv tə liv, wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd bɹʌʃt baɪ hɝ ɪndə ðə tɛnt, pʊʃɪŋ bæk əɹ bændɪd waɪt hʊd. əmɑɹə wɑz ə θɪn wʊmən, ən əz smɔl əz naɪsaʊ. ɪt simd ə stʃɹɔŋ wɪn maɪt bloʊ hɝ əweɪ, jɛt ʃi hæɾ ə vɛɹi fɝm hænd wɪð ðə nɑvəsɪz ɡɪvən ɪndə hɝ kɛɹ, fɝmɝ ðən mɛni sɪstɝz. bʌt ðɛn, ʃi wɑz hɑɹɾ ɑn hɝsɛlf, ən ə nɑvəsəz laɪf wɑz səpoʊz tə bi hɑɹd. əmɑɹəz ɡɹeɪ aɪz ɹoʊl tə ðə fɹɪnʒ ɑn θiədʒɹɪnz ʃɔl, ən əɹ maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪndə ə skɔɹnfəl ɡɹɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃi smuðd ɪɾ əweɪ tə spɹɛɾ əɹ snoʊi, bændɪd skɝts fəɹ ɛɡwin. bɹaɪt spɑts ə kʌlɝ fleɪmd ɑn θiədʒɹɪnz tʃiks.

As the Brown moved to leave, one of the Accepted brushed by her into the tent, pushing back her banded white hood. Emara was a thin woman, and as small as Nisao. It seemed a strong wind might blow her away, yet she had a very firm hand with the novices given into her care, firmer than many sisters. But then, she was hard on herself, and a novice's life was supposed to be hard. Emara's gray eyes rolled to the fringe on Theodrin's shawl, and her mouth twisted into a scornful grin before she smoothed it away to spread her snowy, banded skirts for Egwene. Bright spots of color flamed on Theodrin's cheeks.

ɛɡwin slæpt ə hæn daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə ɹæɾəl ðə stoʊn ɪŋkwɛl ən ðə sæn dʒɑɹ. "hæv jəɹ fɝɡɑɾən haʊ tə bi kɝɾiəs tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃaɪld?" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. əmɑɹə wɛn peɪl - ði æmɪɝlɪn dɪɾ əv ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən, æftɝ ɔl - ən heɪstəli meɪɾ ən ivən dipɝ kɝtsi fəɹ θiədʒɹɪn, hu æknɑlɪdʒd ɪt wɪð ə wʊɾən nɑd bɪfɔɹ ɡlaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə tɛn ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ swɪfli ðən ʃi hæɾ ɛntɝd.

Egwene slapped a hand down on the table hard enough to rattle the stone inkwell and the sand jar. "Have your forgotten how to be courteous to an Aes Sedai, child?" she said sharply. Emara went pale - the Amyrlin did have a reputation, after all - and hastily made an even deeper curtsy for Theodrin, who acknowledged it with a wooden nod before gliding from the tent a good deal more swiftly than she had entered.

wʌɾ əmɑɹə stæmɝɾ aʊt, ɪn ən ɪliɑnɝ æksɛn meɪd θɪkɝ baɪ nɝvz, wɑz ə ɹɪkwɛs fɹəm ləleɪn tə mit wɪð ði æmɪɝlɪn. ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn hæd bɪn mʌtʃ lɛs fɔɹməl, wʌns, əpɪɹɪŋ ʌnənaʊnst ən wɛnɛvɝ ðeɪ wɪʃt, bʌt ðə dɛklɝeɪʃən ʌv wɔɹ ɑn ɪleɪɾə hæd tʃeɪnʒd ə ɡɹeɪt dil.

What Emara stammered out, in an Illianer accent made thicker by nerves, was a request from Lelaine to meet with the Amyrlin. Romanda and Lelaine had been much less formal, once, appearing unannounced and whenever they wished, but the declaration of war on Elaida had changed a great deal.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð. ɛɡwin ɹɪtɝn ðə seɪm ɹɪplaɪ tə ləleɪn ðət ʃi hæd tə ɹoʊmændə, ðoʊ ɪn ə mɔɹ klɪp toʊn, ən əmɑɹə ɔlmoʊs fɛl oʊvɝ meɪkɪŋ əɹ kɝtsi ən pɹæktəkli ɹæn aʊɾ ə ðə tɛnt. wʌn mɔɹ neɪl fæsənɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ðə lɛdʒən ʌv ɛɡwin ælvɪɹ, ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ u meɪd sɛɝl beɪɡən lʊk laɪk ə ɡus-daʊn pɪloʊ.

Not everything, but enough to go on with. Egwene returned the same reply to Lelaine that she had to Romanda, though in a more clipped tone, and Emara almost fell over making her curtsy and practically ran out of the tent. One more nail fastening together the legend of Egwene al'Vere, the Amyrlin Seat who made Sereille Bagand look like a goose-down pillow.

əz sun əz ði æksɛptɪd wɑz ɡɔn, ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd əɹ hæn ən fɹaʊn ət wʌɾ ɪt hæd kʌvɝd.

As soon as the Accepted was gone, Egwene raised her hand and frowned at what it had covered.

ðə foʊldəd skwɛɹ ə peɪpɝ ðət θiədʒɹɪn hæd dəpɑzɪɾɪd ɑn ðə teɪbəl waɪl kɪsɪŋ əɹ ɹɪŋ. hɝ fɹaʊn dipənd wən ʃi oʊpən ɪt. ðə skɹɪp ðət kʌvɝd ðə smɔl peɪdʒ mænədʒ tə floʊ waɪl biɪŋ pɹɪsaɪs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪŋkblɑɾ ɑn wʌn ɛdʒ. θiədʒɹɪn wɑz vɛɹi nit. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənfɔɹm tə ðə dʒɛnɝəl vju ʌv bɹaʊnz.

The folded square of paper that Theodrin had deposited on the table while kissing her ring. Her frown deepened when she opened it. The script that covered the small page managed to flow while being precise, but there was an inkblot on one edge. Theodrin was very neat. Perhaps she was trying to conform to the general view of Browns.

ɹoʊmændə hæz sɛn tu sɪstɝz tə tʃɹævəl tə kɛɹhin ən ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt səm teɪl ðəɾ əz ðə jɛloʊ sɪɾɝz bʌzɪŋ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt ðə ɹumɝ ɪz, mʌðɝ, bʌɾ əl faɪn aʊt. aɪ hɝd wʌn ə ðɛm mɛnʃən nɪneɪiv, nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɪn kɛɹhin, bʌɾ əz ɪf ðə ɹumɝ wɑz sʌmhaʊ kənɛktəd tə hɝ. ðə ful wʊmən hæɾ ivən saɪn əɹ neɪm!

Romanda has sent two sisters to Travel to Cairhien and investigate some tale that has the Yellow Sitters buzzing. I don't know what the rumor is, Mother, but I will find out. I heard one of them mention Nynaeve, not as if she were in Cairhien, but as if the rumor was somehow connected to her. The fool woman had even signed her name!

"wʌɾ ɪz ðæt, mʌðɝ?"

"What is that, Mother?"

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz, ən bɛɹli kɑt ðə foʊldɪŋ tʃɛɹ lɛɡ bɪfɔɹ ɪt dʒɹɑpt əɹ ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts. ʃi ɹifoʊkəst əɹ skaʊl ɑn sɪuən, hu stʊd dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ði ɛntʃɹi flæps wɪð əɹ blufɹɪnd ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz ən əɹ lɛðɝ foʊldɝz pɹɛs tə hɝ bɹɛsts. ðə blu-aɪd wʊmənz aɪbɹaʊz ɹeɪz slaɪtli əɾ ɛɡwinz stɑɹɾəlmənt.

Egwene gave a start of surprise, and barely caught the folding chair leg before it dropped her onto the carpets. She refocused her scowl on Siuan, who stood just inside the entry flaps with her bluefringed shawl on her arms and her leather folders pressed to her breasts. The blue-eyed woman's eyebrows raised slightly at Egwene's startlement.

"hɪɹ," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli, θɹʌstɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ ət hɝ. ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm tə bi dʒʌmpɪŋ ən twɪtʃɪŋ! "ju noʊ əbaʊt kɛɹən?" ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi mʌst, bʌɾ ɛɡwin stɪl sɛd, "hæv jə meɪd ðə nɛsəsɛɹi tʃeɪnʒəz?" nɛsəsɛɹi tʃeɪnʒəz. laɪt, ʃi saʊndəɾ əz pɑmpəs əz ɹoʊmændə. ʃi wɑz ɑn ɛdʒ.

"Here," Egwene said irritably, thrusting the paper at her. This was no time to be jumping and twitching! "You know about Kairen?" Of course, she must, but Egwene still said, "Have you made the necessary changes?" Necessary changes. Light, she sounded as pompous as Romanda. She was on edge.

oʊnli ət ðə læs dɪd ʃi θɪŋk tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ ən wiv ə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ; oʊnli æftɝ ðə wɔɹd wɑz ɪn pleɪs dɪd ʃi θɪŋk ðət tədeɪ maɪt nɑt bi ðə bɛs taɪm fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk ʃi hæd pɹaɪvət mæɾɝz tə dɪskʌs wɪð sɪuən.

Only at the last did she think to embrace saidar and weave a ward against eavesdropping; only after the ward was in place did she think that today might not be the best time for anyone to think she had private matters to discuss with Siuan.

sɪuən wɑz nɑɾ ɑn ɛdʒ. ʃi hæd wɛðɝd stɔɹmz. ən mænədʒ tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm dʒɹaʊnɪŋ, səm maɪt seɪ. tədeɪ wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl wɪndi, tə hɝ. "noʊ niɾ əntɪl wi noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ əbaʊt ðə boʊts, mʌðɝ," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ foʊldɝz ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən nitli skwɛɹɪŋ əm bɪtwin ði ɪŋkwɛl ən ðə sæn dʒɑɹ. "ðə lɛs taɪm boʊɾ əz tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðə lɛs tʃæns ʃɪl pænɪk." kɑm əz ə pɑnd. ivən tu mɝɾɝd sɪstɝz kəd nɑt ɹʌfəl sɪuən. əɹ sɛndɪŋ ə nɑvəs ʌv oʊnli ə fju mʌnθs tə ɹipleɪs wʌn ə ðɛm. ə fɹaʊn kɹist əɹ fɔɹhɛɾ əz ʃi ɹɛd ðə noʊt, ðoʊ. "fɝs fɑoʊleɪn ɡoʊz ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ," ʃi ɡɹaʊld ət ðə peɪpɝ, "ænd naʊ θiədʒɹɪn bɹɪŋz ðɪs tə jə ɪnstɛɾ ə tə mi. ðət ful ɡɝl əz lɛs bɹeɪnz ðən ə fɪʃɝ-bɝd! jud θɪŋk ʃi wɑns sʌmwʌn tə faɪn aʊt ʃiz kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ɹoʊmændə fəɹ ju." kipɪŋ ən aɪ. ə pəlaɪt weɪ ʌv seɪɪŋ "spaɪ." ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ pɹæktəst ɪn jufəmɪzəmz. ðət wɛnt wɪð biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. tədeɪ, jufəmɪzəmz ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɑn ɛɡwin.

Siuan was not on edge. She had weathered storms. And managed to recover from drowning, some might say. Today was only a little windy, to her. "No need until we know for sure about the boats, Mother," she replied calmly, setting her folders on the table and neatly squaring them between the inkwell and the sand jar. "The less time Bode has to think about it, the less chance she'll panic." Calm as a pond. Even two murdered sisters could not ruffle Siuan. Or sending a novice of only a few months to replace one of them. A frown creased her forehead as she read the note, though. "First Faolain goes into hiding," she growled at the paper, "and now Theodrin brings this to you instead of to me. That fool girl has less brains than a fisher-bird! You'd think she wants someone to find out she's keeping an eye on Romanda for you." Keeping an eye. A polite way of saying "spy." They were both practiced in euphemisms. That went with being Aes Sedai. Today, euphemisms grated on Egwene.

"pɝhæps ʃi dʌz wɑnə bi dɪskʌvɝd. pɝhæps ʃiz taɪɝɾ ə ɹoʊmændə tɛlɪŋ əɹ wʌt tə du, wʌt tə seɪ, wʌt tə θɪŋk. aɪ hæɾ ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn hɪɹ u snɪɹɾ ət θiədʒɹɪnz ʃɔl, sɪuən." ði ʌðɝ wʊmən meɪɾ ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ. "ɹoʊmændə tʃɹaɪz tə tɛl ɛvɹiwʌn wʌt tə du. ən wʌt tə θɪŋk.

"Perhaps she does want to be discovered. Perhaps she's tired of Romanda telling her what to do, what to say, what to think. I had an Accepted in here who sneered at Theodrin's shawl, Siuan." The other woman made a dismissive gesture. "Romanda tries to tell everyone what to do. And what to think.

əz fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, θɪŋz wɪl tʃeɪnʒ wʌns θiədʒɹɪn ən fɑoʊleɪn kən swɛɹ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ɛniwʌn wɪl æktʃəli  ɪnsɪs ðeɪ bi tɛstəd fəɹ ðə ʃɔl naʊ. əntɪl ðɛn, ðeɪ mʌs teɪk wʌt kʌmz." "ðæɾ ɪzənt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf, sɪuən." ɛɡwin mænədʒ tə kip əɹ toʊn lɛvəl, bʌɾ ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝt.

As for the rest, things will change once Theodrin and Faolain can swear on the Oath Rod. I don't suppose anyone will actually insist they be tested for the shawl now. Until then, they must take what comes." "That isn't good enough, Siuan." Egwene managed to keep her tone level, but it took an effort.

ʃi hæɾ ət list səspɛktəd wʌt ʃi wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ðoʊz tu ɪn fəɹ wən ʃi toʊld əm tə ətætʃ ðɛmsɛlvz tə ɹoʊmændə ən ləleɪn. ʃi hæd niɾəd tə noʊ wʌt ðə sɪɾɝz wɝ skimɪŋ æt, ən stɪl niɾəd tə noʊ, jɛt ʃi hæɾ ə duɾi tə ðɛm. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðə fɝs tə swɛɹ fiəlti tə hɝ, ən ə ðɛɹ oʊn fɹi wɪl. bɪsaɪdz wɪtʃ. . . . "mʌtʃ ʌv wʌts sɛɾ əbaʊt θiədʒɹɪn ən fɑoʊleɪn kən bi sɛɾ ə mi, tu. ɪf æksɛptɪd kən ʃoʊ ðɛm dɪsɹɪspɛkt. . . . " wɛl, ʃi hæd noʊ fɪɹ ə ðæt. ðə sɪstɝz wɝ ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

She had at least suspected what she was letting those two in for when she told them to attach themselves to Romanda and Lelaine. She had needed to know what the Sitters were scheming at, and still needed to know, yet she had a duty to them. They had been the first to swear fealty to her, and of their own free will. Besides which. . . . "Much of what's said about Theodrin and Faolain can be said of me, too. If Accepted can show them disrespect. . . . " Well, she had no fear of that. The sisters were another matter.

ɪspɛʃli ðə sɪɾɝz. "sɪuən, aɪ hæv noʊ hoʊp əɾ ɔl ə junaɪɾɪŋ ðə taʊɝ ɪf ɛɛs sədaɪ daʊt mi." sɪuən snɔɹɾɪd fɔɹsfəli. "mʌðɝ, baɪ naʊ ivən ləleɪn ən ɹoʊmændə noʊ jəɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðəl ədmɪɾ ɪt. ðət pɛɹ wʊdn əv fɔlən ɪn laɪn wɪð din ɛɹəmən.

Especially the Sitters. "Siuan, I have no hope at all of uniting the Tower if Aes Sedai doubt me." Siuan snorted forcefully. "Mother, by now even Lelaine and Romanda know you're the Amyrlin Seat in truth, whether or not they'll admit it. That pair wouldn't have fallen in line with Deane Aryman.

aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə si jə əz ənʌðɝ ɛdʒɹnə nɔɹɛɡoʊvnə."

I think they're beginning to see you as another Edarna Noregovna."

"ðæts əz meɪ bi," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɹaɪli. din wɑz kənsɪɾɝd ðə waɪt taʊɝz seɪvjɝ, æftɝ bɑnwɪnz dɪzæstɝ wɪð ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ɛdʒɹnə wɑz bɪliv tə hæv bɪn ðə moʊs pəlɪɾɪkəli skɪld wʊmən ɛvɝ tə hoʊl ðə stæf ən stoʊl. boʊθ hæd bɪn vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ æmɪɝlənz. "bʌɾ əz juv ɹimaɪndəd mi, aɪ hæv tə meɪk ʃʊɹ aɪ doʊn ɛn ʌp laɪk ʃaɪn tʃʌŋk." ʃaɪn hæd bɪɡʌn əz ə stʃɹɔŋ æmɪɝlɪn, fɝmli ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðə taʊɝ ən ðə hɔl, ən ɛndəɾ əz ə pʌpət duɪŋ ɪɡzækli əz ʃi wɑz toʊld.

"That's as may be," Egwene said dryly. Deane was considered the White Tower's savior, after Bonwhin's disaster with Artur Hawkwing. Edarna was believed to have been the most politically skilled woman ever to hold the staff and stole. Both had been very strong Amyrlins. "But as you've reminded me, I have to make sure I don't end up like Shein Chunk." Shein had begun as a strong Amyrlin, firmly in charge of the Tower and the Hall, and ended as a puppet doing exactly as she was told.

sɪuən nɑɾəd, ɪn əpɹuvəl ən əɡɹimənt. ʃi ɹɪli wɑz titʃɪŋ ɛɡwin ðə taʊɝz hɪstɝi, ən ʃi ɔfən bɹɔɾ ʌp æmɪɝlənz u hæd mɪsstɛp feɪɾəli. ɪnkluɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "ðɪs ɪz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ, ðoʊ," ʃi mʌɾɝd, tæpɪŋ ðə noʊɾ əɡɛnst əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. "wɛn aɪ leɪ maɪ hænz ɑn θiədʒɹɪn, əl meɪk əɹ wɪʃ ʃi wɑz ə nɑvəs. ən fɑoʊleɪn! ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ kən ʃɝk ɔf naʊ, aɪ swɛɹ, əl ɡʌt ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm laɪk ɡɹʌntɝz ɑn ðə dɑk!" "jul ɡʌt hu?" ʃɛɹiəm æskt əz ʃi wɔkt ɪn θɹu ðə wɔɹɾ ɪn ə ɡʌst ə koʊld ɛɹ.

Siuan nodded, in approval and agreement. She really was teaching Egwene the Tower's history, and she often brought up Amyrlins who had misstepped fatally. Including herself. "This is another matter, though," she muttered, tapping the note against her fingers. "When I lay my hands on Theodrin, I'll make her wish she was a novice. And Faolain! If they think they can shirk off now, I swear, I'll gut the pair of them like grunters on the dock!" "You'll gut who?" Sheriam asked as she walked in through the ward in a gust of cold air.

ɛɡwinz tʃɛɹ ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑpt əɹ ɑntu ðə kɑɹpəts əɡɛn. ʃi niɾəd tə ɡɛɾ ə tʃɛɹ ðət dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə foʊld ʌp ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi muvd. ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə bɛɾ ɛdʒɹnə nɛvɝ dʒʌmpt əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɪtʃhoʊk daʊn əɹ bæk.

Egwene's chair almost dropped her onto the carpets again. She needed to get a chair that did not try to fold up every time she moved. She was willing to bet Edarna never jumped as if she had itchoak down her back.

"noʊ wʌn u kənsɝnz ju," sɪuən sɛd kɑmli, pʊɾɪŋ ðə peɪpɝ tə wʌn ə ðə teɪbəl-læmps fleɪmz. ɪt bɝn kwɪkli, ɹaɪt tə hɝ fɪŋɡɝtɪps, ən ðən ʃi mæʃt ɪɾ aʊt bɪtwin əɹ hænz ən bɹʌʃt ði æʃ əweɪ. oʊnli ɛɡwin, sɪuən ən lin nu ðə tʃɹuθ ə fɑoʊleɪn ən θiədʒɹɪn. ən ðə tu sɪstɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, ʌv kɔɹs. ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt dil niðɝ ə ðɛm nu, iðɝ. ʃɛɹiəm æksɛptɪd ðə ɹɪbʌf wɪð ikwənɪmɪɾi. ðə faɪɝ-hɛɹd wʊmən sim tə hæv ɹəkʌvɝd kəmplitli fɹəm əɹ kəlæps ɪn ðə hɔl. ət list, ʃi hæd ɹəkʌvɝɾ əɹ aʊɾɝ dɪɡnəɾi, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. wɑtʃɪŋ sɪuən bɝn ðə noʊt, hɝ tɪltəd ɡɹin aɪz maɪɾ əv taɪɾənd ə lɪɾəl, ən ʃi dɪd tʌtʃ ðə nɛɹoʊ blu stoʊl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝz əz ɪf tə ɹimaɪn hɝsɛlf ðəɾ ɪt wɑz.

"No one who concerns you," Siuan said calmly, putting the paper to one of the table-lamp's flames. It burned quickly, right to her fingertips, and then she mashed it out between her hands and brushed the ash away. Only Egwene, Siuan and Leane knew the truth of Faolain and Theodrin. And the two sisters themselves, of course. Though there was a great deal neither of them knew, either. Sheriam accepted the rebuff with equanimity. The fire-haired woman seemed to have recovered completely from her collapse in the Hall. At least, she had recovered her outer dignity, for the most part. Watching Siuan burn the note, her tilted green eyes might have tightened a little, and she did touch the narrow blue stole hanging from her shoulders as if to remind herself that it was.

ðɛɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə æksɛp sɪuənz ɔɹɾɝz  -  pʊɾɪŋ əɹ kipɝ ɪn ðət pəzɪʃən hæd sim tu hɑɹʃ tə ɛɡwin, ɪn ði ɛnd  -  bʌt ʃɛɹiəm nu vɛɹi wɛl ðət sɪuən hæd noʊ nid tə æksɛpt əɹ ɔɹɾɝz iðɝ, wɪtʃ hæd tə ɡɔl əɹ naʊ ðət sɪuən stʊd soʊ fɑɹ bɪniθ əɹ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. noʊɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ sikɹəts ʃi wɑz nɑt pɹɪvi tə hæd tə ɡɔl hɝ, əz wɛl. ʃɛɹiəm wəɾ əv tə lɪv wɪð ɪt ðoʊ.

there. She did not have to accept Siuan's orders  -  putting her Keeper in that position had seemed too harsh to Egwene, in the end  -  but Sheriam knew very well that Siuan had no need to accept her orders either, which had to gall her now that Siuan stood so far beneath her in the Power. Knowing there were secrets she was not privy to had to gall her, as well. Sheriam would have to live with it though.

ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæd bɹɔɾ ə peɪpɝ, wɪtʃ ʃi leɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛɡwin. "aɪ mɛt tiɑnə ɑn ðə weɪ hɪɹ, mʌðɝ, ən toʊld əɹ aɪd ɡɪv ðɪs tə ju."

She also had brought a paper, which she laid on the table in front of Egwene. "I met Tiana on the way here, Mother, and told her I'd give this to you."

"ðɪs" wɑz ðə deɪz ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn ɹʌnəweɪz, ðoʊ ðoʊz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ keɪm ɛvɹi deɪ, əɹ ivən ɛvɹi wik, sɪns ðə nɑvəsɪz hæd bɪn ɔɹɡənaɪzd ɪndə fæmliz. kʌzənz səpɔɹɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ θɹu fɹəstʃɹeɪʃənz ən tɪɹz, ən mænədʒ tə tɔk wʌn ənʌðɝ aʊɾ ə ðə wɝs mɪsteɪks, laɪk ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ.

"This" was the day's report on runaways, though those no longer came every day, or even every week, since the novices had been organized into families. Cousins supported one another through frustrations and tears, and managed to talk one another out of the worst mistakes, like running away.

ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn neɪm ɑn ðə peɪdʒ. nɪkoʊlə tʃɹihɪl.

There was only one name on the page. Nicola Treehill.

ɛɡwin saɪɾ ən sɛt ðə peɪpɝ daʊn. ʃi wʊɾə θɔt nɪkoʊləz ɡɹid fəɹ lɝnɪŋ wʊɾə kɛpt əɹ fit stɪl noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd ðə wʊmən ɡɹu. ən jɛt, ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ ʃi wɑz sɑɹi tə si ði ɛn ə hɝ. nɪkoʊlə wɑz kənaɪvɪŋ ən ənskɹupjələs, wɪlɪŋ tə tʃɹaɪ blækmeɪl əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ʃi θɔt wəɾ ədvæns hɝ. vɛɹi laɪkli ʃi hæd hæd hɛlp. ɑɹinə wəd nɑɾ əv bɔkt ət stilɪŋ hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tə fli.

Egwene sighed and set the paper down. She would have thought Nicola's greed for learning would have kept her feet still no matter how frustrated the woman grew. And yet, she could not say she was sorry to see the end of her. Nicola was conniving and unscrupulous, willing to try blackmail or whatever else she thought would advance her. Very likely she had had help. Areina would not have balked at stealing horses for the pair of them to flee.

əbɹʌpli, ðə deɪt bɪsaɪd ðə neɪm kɑɾ əɹ aɪ. tu deɪts, æktʃəli , mɑɹkt əz kwɛstʃənz.

Abruptly, the date beside the name caught her eye. Two dates, actually, marked as questions.

mʌnθs wɝ sɛldəm neɪmd, mʌtʃ lɛs deɪz nʌmbɝd, ɪksɛpt ɪn əfɪʃəl dɑkjəməns ən tʃɹiɾiz.

Months were seldom named, much less days numbered, except in official documents and treaties.

saɪnd, sild ən wɪtnəst ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv ɪljən ɑn ðə twɛlfθ deɪ ʌv sævən, ðɪs jɪɹ ʌv ɡɹeɪs. . . .

Signed, sealed and witnessed in the city of Illian on the twelfth day of Saven, this Year of Grace. . . .

ən fəɹ ɹɪpɔɹts ə ðɪs neɪtʃɝ, ən ɛntɝɪŋ ə wʊmənz neɪm ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk. fəɹ kɑmən jus, soʊ mɛni deɪz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs fistdeɪ əɹ æftɝ ðət səfaɪst. ɹɪɾən aʊt, deɪts ɔlweɪz lʊkt ə lɪɾəl stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hɝ. ʃi hæd tə kaʊn ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz tə bi ʃʊɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi sɔ.

And for reports of this nature, and entering a woman's name in the novice book. For common use, so many days before this feastday or after that sufficed. Written out, dates always looked a little strange to her. She had to count on her fingers to be sure of what she saw.

"nɪkoʊlə ɹæn əweɪ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ deɪz əɡoʊ, ʃɛɹiəm, ən tiɑnə ɪz dʒʌst ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ ɪt? ʃi ɪzən ivən ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz θɹi deɪz əɹ fɔɹ?"

"Nicola ran away three or four days ago, Sheriam, and Tiana is just reporting it? She isn't even sure whether it was three days or four?"

"nɪkoʊləz kʌzənz kʌvɝd fəɹ hɝ, mʌðɝ." ʃɛɹiəm ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hɝ smɔl smaɪl simd əmjuzd, ðoʊ.

"Nicola's cousins covered for her, Mother." Sheriam shook her head ruefully. Strangely, her small smile seemed amused, though.

əɹ ivən ædmaɪɹɪŋ. "nɑt fɹəm lʌv; əpɛɹənli, ðeɪ wɝ ɡlæd tə si ðə tʃaɪld ɡoʊ ən əfɹeɪd ʃid bi bɹɔt bæk. ʃi wɑz kwaɪɾ oʊvɝbɛɹɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ tælən ət fɔɹtɛlɪŋ. aɪm əfɹeɪd tiɑnə ɪz vɛɹi əpsɛt wɪð ðɛm. nʌn wɪl bi sɪɾɪŋ kʌmfɝɾəbli ɪn ðɛɹ klæsəz tədeɪ, əɹ fəɹ deɪz tə kʌm, aɪ fɪɹ.

Or even admiring. "Not from love; apparently, they were glad to see the child go and afraid she'd be brought back. She was quite overbearing about her Talent at Foretelling. I'm afraid Tiana is very upset with them. None will be sitting comfortably in their classes today, or for days to come, I fear.

tiɑnə sɛz ʃi ɪntɛnz tə ɡɪv əm itʃ ə doʊs ə ðə stʃɹæp ɪnstɛɾ ə bɹɛkfəst ɛvɹi deɪ tɪl nɪkoʊlə ɪz faʊnd. aɪ θɪŋk ʃi maɪt ɹɪlɛnt, ðoʊ. wɪð nɪkoʊlə ɡɔn soʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ əɹ flaɪt wɑz dɪskʌvɝd, ɪt meɪ bi səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃiz loʊkeɪɾəd."

Tiana says she intends to give them each a dose of the strap instead of breakfast every day till Nicola is found. I think she might relent, though. With Nicola gone so long before her flight was discovered, it may be some time before she's located."

ɛɡwin wɪnst slaɪtli. ʃi kəd ɹikɔl əɹ oʊn vɪzəts tə ðə stʌɾi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz, ðən ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ðə vɛɹi wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ʃɛɹiəm hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ ɑɹm. ə deɪli doʊs wəd bi fɪɹs. bʌt haɪɾɪŋ ə ɹʌnəweɪz flaɪt wɑz mɔɹ sɪɹiəs ðən snikɪŋ aʊɾ æftɝ aʊɝz əɹ pʊlɪŋ ə pɹæŋk.

Egwene winced slightly. She could recall her own visits to the study of the Mistress of Novices, then occupied by the very woman in front of her. Sheriam had a strong arm. A daily dose would be fierce. But hiding a runaway's flight was more serious than sneaking out after hours or pulling a prank.

ʃi pʊʃt ðə ɹipɔɹt tə wʌn saɪd.

She pushed the report to one side.

"tiɑnə wɪl hændəl ɪɾ əz ʃi siz fɪt," ʃi sɛd. "ʃɛɹiəm, hæz ðəɹ bɪn ɛni tʃeɪnʒ ɪn haʊ ðə sɪstɝz tɔk əbaʊt maɪ dʒɹim?" ʃi hæd ɹɪvil ðə dʒɹim əbaʊɾ ə sintʃæn ətæk ðə vɛɹi mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ dʒɹimɪŋ ɪt, ən ðə wɪmən ʃi toʊl stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ æpəθɛɾɪkli, əpɛɹənli kəz ə ðə fɹɛʃnəs ʌv æneɪjəz dɛθ. ðət hæd stʌn ɛvɹiwʌn.

"Tiana will handle it as she sees fit," she said. "Sheriam, has there been any change in how the sisters talk about my dream?" She had revealed the dream about a Seanchan attack the very morning after dreaming it, and the women she told stared at her apathetically, apparently because of the freshness of Anaiya's death. That had stunned everyone.

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ, ʃɛɹiəm klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən smuðd əɹ blu-slæʃt skɝts. "ju meɪ nɑt bi əwɛɹ, mʌðɝ, bʌt wʌn ə nɪkoʊləz kʌzənz ɪz lɑɹini aɪɛlɪn. fɹəm ɛmənz fild," ʃi æɾəd, əz ɪf ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊ ðæt. "noʊ wʌn wəd θɪŋk jə wɝ pleɪɪŋ feɪvɹɪts ɪf jə pɑɹɾənd ðə hoʊl fæmli. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi ɹɪləns, tiɑnə dʌz min tə bi vɛɹi ʃɑɹp wɪð əm ɪn ðə mintaɪm. ðəl sʌfɝ."

Instead of answering, Sheriam cleared her throat and smoothed her blue-slashed skirts. "You may not be aware, Mother, but one of Nicola's cousins is Larine Ayellin. From Emond's Field," she added, as if Egwene did not know that. "No one would think you were playing favorites if you pardoned the whole family. Whether or not she relents, Tiana does mean to be very sharp with them in the meantime. They will suffer."

linɪŋ bæk, kɛɹfəli kəz ə ðə wɑbəli tʃɛɹ lɛɡ, ɛɡwin fɹaʊn ʌp ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. lɑɹini wɑz ɔlmoʊs ðə seɪm eɪdʒ əz ʃi, ən ə kloʊs fɹɛnd ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp. ðeɪ hæd spɛn aʊɝz təɡɛðɝ, ɡɑsəpɪŋ ən pɹæktəsɪŋ pʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛɹ ɪn bɹeɪdz fəɹ wən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl sɛd ðeɪ wɝ oʊld ɪnʌf.

Leaning back, carefully because of the wobbly chair leg, Egwene frowned up at the other woman. Larine was almost the same age as she, and a close friend growing up. They had spent hours together, gossiping and practicing putting their hair in braids for when the Women's Circle said they were old enough.

dɪspaɪt ðæt, lɑɹini hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fju ɛmənz fild ɡɝlz u sim tə æksɛp ðəɾ ɛɡwin maɪt ɹɪli bi ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ðoʊ ʃi ʃoʊɾ ɪt meɪnli baɪ kipɪŋ əɹ dɪstəns. bʌt dɪd ʃɛɹiəm θɪŋk ɛɡwin wəd pleɪ feɪvɹɪts? ivən sɪuən lʊk teɪkən əbæk. "ju ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛniwʌn, ʃɛɹiəm, nɑvəs dɪsəplən ɪz ðə pɹɑvəns ə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. ənlɛs ə ɡɝl ɪz biɪŋ əbjuzd, ɛniweɪ, ən jə hævən sədʒɛstəd ðæt. bɪsaɪdz, ɪf lɑɹini θɪŋks ʃi kən ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð hɛlpɪŋ ə ɹʌnəweɪ tədeɪ - hɛlpɪŋ ə ɹʌnəweɪ, ʃɛɹiəm! - wʌt wɪl ʃi θɪŋk ʃi kən ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð təmɑɹoʊ?

Despite that, Larine had been one of the few Emond's Field girls who seemed to accept that Egwene might really be the Amyrlin Seat, though she showed it mainly by keeping her distance. But did Sheriam think Egwene would play favorites? Even Siuan looked taken aback. "You should know better than anyone, Sheriam, novice discipline is the province of the Mistress of Novices. Unless a girl is being abused, anyway, and you haven't suggested that. Besides, if Larine thinks she can get away with helping a runaway today - helping a runaway, Sheriam! - what will she think she can get away with tomorrow?

ʃi kən ɹitʃ ðə ʃɔl, ɪf ʃiz ðə ɡʌmpʃən tə stɪk wɪð ɪt. aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əɹ daʊn ə pæθ ðəɾ ɛnz wɪð əɹ biɪŋ sɛn əweɪ fəɹ mɪsbəheɪvjɝ. naʊ. wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ seɪɪŋ əbaʊt maɪ dʒɹim?" ʃɛɹiəmz tɪltəd ɡɹin aɪz blɪŋkt, ən ʃi ɡlænst ət sɪuən. laɪt, ðə wʊmən θɔɾ ɛɡwin wɑz biɪŋ hɑɹd kəz sɪuən wɑz pɹɛzənt? kəz sɪuən maɪt kæɹi teɪlz? ʃi ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ; ʃi aɪ bin ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz. "ði æɾətud əmʌŋ ðə sɪstɝz, mʌðɝ," ʃɛɹiəm sɛd faɪnəli, "ɪz stɪl ðət ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ ə θaʊzən maɪlz əweɪ, ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə tʃɹævəl, ən ɪf ðeɪ stɑɹt mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪl lɝn ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɪðɪn tu hʌnʒɹəd liɡz." sɪuən mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ ðət saʊndəd vaɪl, bʌt nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd. ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə kɝs, tu. wɝiz oʊvɝ æneɪjəz mɝɾɝ hæd hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə sɪstɝz' æpəθi. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz ə dʒɹimɝ. æneɪjə hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ æneɪjə wɑz dɛd. sɪuən ən lin bɪlivd, jɛt niðɝ stʊd haɪ ɪnʌf naʊ tə bi lɪsən tə wɪð mɔɹ hɑn ɪmpeɪʃən pəlaɪtnəs, ɪf ðæt. ən ɪt wɑz kwaɪt klɪɹ ðət ʃɛɹiəm dɪd nɑt bɪliv. ʃi oʊbeɪɾ əɹ oʊθ ə fiəlti əz skɹupjələsli əz ɛɡwin cʊɾə wɪʃt fɔɹ, bʌt jə kəd nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝ sʌmwʌn tə bɪliv. ðeɪ oʊnli maʊðd wʌt jə toʊl ðɛm, ən nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. wən ʃɛɹiəm lɛft, ɛɡwin faʊn hɝsɛlf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt hæd bɹɔt ðə wʊmən ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. kəɾ ɪɾ əv bɪn dʒʌs tə pɔɪn aʊt ðət lɑɹini wɑz gɑnə bi pʌnɪʃt? ʃʊɹli nɑt. bʌt ʃi hæd sɛd nʌθɪŋ ɛls, əpɑɹt fɹəm ænsɝɪŋ ɛɡwinz kwɛstʃənz. ʃɔɹtli, maɪɹɛl ɝaɪvd, fɑloʊd kloʊsli baɪ mɔɹvɹɪn. ɛɡwin kəd fil itʃ ə ðɛm ɹilis ðə sɔɹs bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛntɝd ðə tɛnt, ən ðeɪ lɛf ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz weɪɾɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. ivən ɪn bɹif ɡlɪmpsɪz əz ði ɛntʃɹi flæps wɝ pʊʃt əsaɪd, ðə mɛn lʊkt wɛɹi, ivən fəɹ wɔɹɾɝz.

She can reach the shawl, if she has the gumption to stick with it. I won't lead her down a path that ends with her being sent away for misbehavior. Now. What are they saying about my dream?" Sheriam's tilted green eyes blinked, and she glanced at Siuan. Light, the woman thought Egwene was being hard because Siuan was present? Because Siuan might carry tales? She should know better; she I Wbeen the Mistress of Novices. "The attitude among the sisters, Mother," Sheriam said finally, "is still that the Seanchan are a thousand miles away, they don't know how to Travel, and if they start marching on Tar Valon, we'll learn of it before they're within two hundred leagues." Siuan muttered something under her breath that sounded vile, but not surprised. Egwene wanted to curse, too. Worries over Anaiya's murder had had nothing to do with the sisters' apathy. They did not believe that Egwene was a Dreamer. Anaiya had been sure, but Anaiya was dead. Siuan and Leane believed, yet neither stood high enough now to be listened to with more han impatient politeness, if that. And it was quite clear that Sheriam did not believe. She obeyed her oath of fealty as scrupulously as Egwene could have wished for, but you could not order someone to believe. They only mouthed what you told them, and nothing changed. When Sheriam left, Egwene found herself wondering what had brought the woman in the first place. Could it have been just to point out that Larine was going to be punished? Surely not. But she had said nothing else, apart from answering Egwene's questions. Shortly, Myrelle arrived, followed closely by Morvrin. Egwene could feel each of them release the Source before she entered the tent, and they left their Warders waiting outside. Even in brief glimpses as the entry flaps were pushed aside, the men looked wary, even for Warders.

maɪɹɛlz bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz flæʃt ət ðə saɪɾ ə sɪuən, ən əɹ nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹd. mɔɹvɹɪnz ɹaʊn feɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð əz pɑlɪʃt stoʊn, bʌt ʃi bɹʌʃt əɹ dɑɹk bɹaʊn skɝts wɪð boʊθ hænz əz ɪf waɪpɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɔf. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ʌnkɑnʃəs. ənlaɪk ʃɛɹiəm, ðeɪ dɪɾ əv tə æksɛp sɪuənz ɔɹɾɝz, ən niðɝ laɪk ðəɾ əɾ ɔl. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑntəd tə ɡɹaɪn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz, bʌt ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd sɪuən, ən oʊðz əɹ noʊ oʊðz, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli tʃɹʌs ðɛm. nɑt tə ðə dɪɡɹi ʃi dɪd sɪuən. bɪsaɪdz, ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz ɪt wɑz ɪnkənvinjən ɪf nɑɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl fəɹ əɹ tə tɛl ðə sɪstɝz swɔɹn tə hɝ wʌt ʃi wɑntəd dʌn. sɪuən kəd kæɹi mɛsədʒəz, ən ðɪs weɪ, ɛɡwin kəd bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ oʊbeɪd. ʃi æskt əbaʊt tɔk ə hɝ dʒɹim stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ, bʌɾ ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ðɛɹ stɔɹiz wɝ ðə seɪm əz ʃɛɹiəmz.

Myrelle's big dark eyes flashed at the sight of Siuan, and her nostrils flared. Morvrin's round face remained smooth as polished stone, but she brushed her dark brown skirts with both hands as if wiping something off. Perhaps it was unconscious. Unlike Sheriam, they did have to accept Siuan's orders, and neither liked that at all. It was not that Egwene wanted to grind their noses, but she trusted Siuan, and oaths or no oaths, she did not entirely trust them. Not to the degree she did Siuan. Besides, there were times it was inconvenient if not impossible for her to tell the sisters sworn to her what she wanted done. Siuan could carry messages, and this way, Egwene could be sure they were obeyed. She asked about talk of her dream straightaway, but unsurprisingly, their stories were the same as Sheriam's.

ðə sintʃæn wɝ fɑɹ ɔf. ðəɹ wəd bi plɛnti ʌv wɔɹnɪŋ ʃəd ðət tʃeɪnʒ. ðə stɔɹi hæd bɪn ðə seɪm fəɹ ə ɡʊd wik ən ə hæf. wɝs. . . . "ɪt maɪt bi dɪfɹən ɪf æneɪjə wɝ əlaɪv," mɔɹvɹɪn sɛd, bælənsɪŋ ətɑp wʌn ə ðə ɹɪkəɾi stulz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl. ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝ bʌlk, ʃi dɪɾ ɪɾ izəli ən ɡɹeɪsfəli. "æneɪjə hæɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ ɑɹkeɪn nɑlədʒ. aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ʃi ʃʊɾə tʃoʊzən bɹaʊn, maɪsɛlf. ɪf ʃi sɛd jə wɝ ə dʒɹimɝ - " hɝ tiθ klɪkt ʃʌɾ əɾ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk fɹəm ɛɡwin. maɪɹɛl sʌɾənli tʊk ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz ət ðə bɹeɪziɝ. niðɝ ə ðɛm bɪlivd, iðɝ. ɪksɛp fəɹ sɪuən ən lin, noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə hoʊl kæmp bɪliv ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd hæɾ ə tʃɹu dʒɹim. vɛɹɪlɪn hæd teɪkən oʊvɝ ðə tɔks ɪn dɛɹn, dɛfli pʊʃɪŋ bioʊnɪn ɪndə ə lɛsɝ ɹoʊl, ən ʃi ɔfɝd kɑnstən ɪkskjusɪz əz tə waɪ ʃi kəd nɑt pæs ɑn ə wɔɹnɪŋ ət dʒʌs ðɪs moʊmənt. pɝhæps ɪn ə fju deɪz, wən ðə tɔks wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ mɔɹ smuðli. əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən sɪstɝz tɔkɪŋ ɪn sɝkəlz wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ə wɝd ðət maɪt sɛn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ əweɪ əfɛndəd. noʊ wʌn əɾ ɔl bʌt sɪuən ən lin. ʃi θɔt ðeɪ bɪlivd. maɪɹɛl tɝn fɹəm ðə bɹeɪziɝ əz ɪf stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə koʊlz. "mʌðɝ, aɪ hæv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə deɪ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd - " ʃi bɹoʊk ɔf ən tɝn bæk tə ðə bɹeɪziɝ əz ə lɔŋ-feɪst wʊmən ɪn dip blu ɛntɝd ðə tɛn kæɹiɪŋ ə θɹiləɡd stul peɪntəɾ ɪn bɹaɪt spaɪɹəlz. meɪɡɑn wɑz bjuɾəfəl, wɪð lɑɹdʒ aɪz ən fʊl lɪps, bʌt ʃi simd ɪlɔŋɡeɪɾəd sʌmhaʊ. ʃi wɑz nɑt ðət tɔl, bʌɾ ivən əɹ hænz sim lɔŋ. ʃi ɡeɪv mɔɹvɹɪn ə kul nɑd, ən pɔɪntɪdli ɪɡnɔɹd maɪɹɛl. "aɪ bɹɔt maɪ oʊn sit tədeɪ, mʌðɝ," ʃi sɛd, meɪkɪŋ əz mʌtʃ ʌv ə kɝtsi əz ʃi kəd wɪð ðə stul ɪn wʌn hænd.

The Seanchan were far off. There would be plenty of warning should that change. The story had been the same for a good week and a half. Worse. . . . "It might be different if Anaiya were alive," Morvrin said, balancing atop one of the rickety stools in front of the writing table. In spite of her bulk, she did it easily and gracefully. "Anaiya had a reputation for arcane knowledge. I always thought she should have chosen Brown, myself. If she said you were a Dreamer - " Her teeth clicked shut at a sharp look from Egwene. Myrelle suddenly took an interest in warming her hands at the brazier. Neither of them believed, either. Except for Siuan and Leane, no one in the whole camp believed that Egwene had had a true dream. Varilin had taken over the talks in Darein, deftly pushing Beonin into a lesser role, and she offered constant excuses as to why she could not pass on a warning at just this moment. Perhaps in a few days, when the talks were going more smoothly. As if they were ever anything other than sisters talking in circles without saying a word that might send the other side away offended. No one at all but Siuan and Leane. She thought they believed. Myrelle turned from the brazier as if steeling herself to put a hand on the coals. "Mother, I have been thinking about the day Shadar Logoth was destroyed - " She broke off and turned back to the brazier as a long-faced woman in deep blue entered the tent carrying a threelegged stool painted in bright spirals. Maigan was beautiful, with large eyes and full lips, but she seemed elongated somehow. She was not that tall, but even her hands seemed long. She gave Morvrin a cool nod, and pointedly ignored Myrelle. "I brought my own seat today, Mother," she said, making as much of a curtsy as she could with the stool in one hand.

"jʊɹz ɑɹ ɹæðɝ ənstɛɾi, ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ."

"Yours are rather unsteady, if I may say so."

ɪt hæd kʌm əz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ æneɪjəz dɛθ mɛn ðə blu ədʒɑ wəd neɪm sʌmwʌn ɛls tə ɛɡwinz "ædvaɪzɝi kaʊnsəl," bʌt ʃi hæd hoʊp fəɹ ðə bɛst wən ʃi lɝn u ɪt wɑz tə bi. meɪɡɑn hæd bɪn wʌn ə sɪuənz ælaɪz wən sɪuən wɑz æmɪɝlɪn. "du jə maɪn ɪf aɪ sɛn sɪuən fəɹ ti, mʌðɝ?" meɪɡɑn sɛɾ əz ʃi sɛɾəld ɑntu hɝ stul. "ju ɹɪli ʃəɾ əv ə nɑvəs əɹ æksɛptɪd tə ɹʌn ɛɹənz, bʌt sɪuən wɪl du."

It had come as no surprise that Anaiya's death meant the Blue Ajah would name someone else to Egwene's "advisory council," but she had hoped for the best when she learned who it was to be. Maigan had been one of Siuan's allies when Siuan was Amyrlin. "Do you mind if I send Siuan for tea, Mother?" Maigan said as she settled onto her stool. "You really should have a novice or Accepted to run errands, but Siuan will do."

"ðə nɑvəsɪz əv ðɛɹ klæsəz, dɔɾɝ," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd, "æn ivən wɪð ði ɝeɪnʒmənt ə fæmliz, ði æksɛptɪd hɑɹdli hæv taɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn stʌɾiz." bɪsaɪdz wɪtʃ, ʃi wəɾ əv tə sɛn ə nɑvəs əɹ æksɛptɪd tə stæn ɪn ðə koʊld ɛni taɪm ʃi wɑntəd tə spik tə sʌmwʌn ɪn pɹaɪvəsi. hɑɹɾ ɑn wʌn u wəd nɑt jɛɾ əv bɪn tɔt haʊ tə ɪɡnɔɹ hiɾ əɹ koʊld, ən ə flæɡ plæntəɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə tɛn tɛlɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ðəɹ maɪt bi sʌmθɪŋ wɝθ ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn. "sɪuən, wɪl jə pliz bɹɪŋ əs səm ti? aɪm ʃʊɹ wi kəɾ ɔl də wɪð ə hɑt kʌp."

"The novices have their classes, Daughter," Egwene replied, "and even with the arrangement of families, the Accepted hardly have time for their own studies." Besides which, she would have to send a novice or Accepted to stand in the cold any time she wanted to speak to someone in privacy. Hard on one who would not yet have been taught how to ignore heat or cold, and a flag planted outside the tent telling everyone there might be something worth eavesdropping on. "Siuan, will you please bring us some tea? I'm sure we could all do with a hot cup."

meɪɡɑn ɹeɪzd ə lɔŋ-fɪŋɡɝd hæn əz sɪuən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ði ɛntʃɹəns. "aɪ hæv ə dʒɑɹ ə mɪn hʌni ɪn maɪ tɛnt," ʃi sɛɾ ɪmpɪɹiəsli. "fɛtʃ ðæt. ən maɪn jə doʊn fɪltʃ ɛni. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ jə juz tə hæv ə swit tuθ. hɝi, naʊ." meɪɡɑn hæd bɪn ən ælaɪ. naʊ ʃi wɑz wʌn ə mɛni sɪstɝz u bleɪm sɪuən fəɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

Maigan raised a long-fingered hand as Siuan started for the entrance. "I have a jar of mint honey in my tent," she said imperiously. "Fetch that. And mind you don't filch any. I remember you used to have a sweet tooth. Hurry, now." Maigan had been an ally. Now she was one of many sisters who blamed Siuan for breaking the White Tower.

"æz jə seɪ, meɪɡɑn," sɪuən ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə mik vɔɪs, ən ivən bɛn əɹ ni slaɪtli bɪfɔɹ ʃi hɝiɾ aʊt. ən ʃi dɪd hɝi. meɪɡɑn stʊɾ əz haɪ əz maɪɹɛl əɹ mɔɹvɹɪn, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɔɹɾɝz əɹ oʊðz ə fiəlti tə pɹətɛkt əɹ hɪɹ. ðə lɔŋ-feɪst wʊmən ɡeɪv ə smɔl, sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. sɪuən hæd hæd tə bɛɡ tə bi æksɛptɪd bæk ɪndə ðə blu ədʒɑ, ən ɹumɝ hæɾ ɪt ðət meɪɡɑn hæd bɪn ðə moʊst ɪnsɪstən ɑn ðə bɛɡɪŋ.

"As you say, Maigan," Siuan replied in a meek voice, and even bent her knee slightly before she hurried out. And she did hurry. Maigan stood as high as Myrelle or Morvrin, and there were no orders or oaths of fealty to protect her here. The long-faced woman gave a small, satisfied nod. Siuan had had to beg to be accepted back into the Blue Ajah, and rumor had it that Maigan had been the most insistent on the begging.

mɔɹvɹɪn meɪɾ əɹ ɪkskjusɪz tə liv bɪhaɪn sɪuən, pɝhæps minɪŋ tə kætʃ əɹ ʌp fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt maɪɹɛl tʊk wʌn ə ðə stulz ən ɛnɡeɪdʒd ɪn ə kɑmpətɪʃən wɪð meɪɡɑn: hu kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ði ʌðɝ moʊs kəmplitli. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ði ænəmɑsəɾi bɪtwin ðə tu wɪmən.

Morvrin made her excuses to leave behind Siuan, perhaps meaning to catch her up for some reason, but Myrelle took one of the stools and engaged in a competition with Maigan: who could ignore the other most completely. Egwene did not understand the animosity between the two women.

səmtaɪmz, pipəl dʒʌs dɪslaɪkt wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt dɪd nɑt meɪk fəɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən.

Sometimes, people just disliked one another. In any case, it did not make for conversation.

ɛɡwin tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə lif θɹu ðə peɪdʒəz ɪn sɪuənz foʊldɝz, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɹumɝz aʊɾ ʌv ɪljən ən ɪnjuɛndoʊz aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin. ðəɹ sim nʌθɪŋ tə əkaʊn fəɹ θiədʒɹɪnz kleɪm ʌv ə teɪl ðət hæd sɛt ðə jɛloʊ sɪɾɝz bʌzɪŋ. sɪuən wʊɾə sɛd sʌmθɪŋ, ɪf ʃi hæd noʊn. meɪɡɑn ən maɪɹɛl stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ əz ɪf wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ tɝn oʊvɝ ʃits ə peɪpɝ wɑz ðə moʊst ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ æktɪvəɾi ɪn ðə wɝld. ʃi wʊɾə sɛn əm boʊθ əweɪ, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə faɪn aʊt wʌt maɪɹɛl hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə deɪ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ hæd bɪn skupt aʊɾ ə ði ɝθ. ʃi kəd nɑt sɛnd wʌn əweɪ wɪθaʊt sɛndɪŋ boʊθ. dʒɹæt ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm!

Egwene took the opportunity to leaf through the pages in Siuan's folders, but she could not concentrate on rumors out of Illian and innuendoes out of Cairhien. There seemed nothing to account for Theodrin's claim of a tale that had set the Yellow Sitters buzzing. Siuan would have said something, if she had known. Maigan and Myrelle stared at her as if watching her turn over sheets of paper was the most interesting activity in the world. She would have sent them both away, but she wanted to find out what Myrelle had been thinking about the day Shadar Logoth had been scooped out of the earth. She could not send one away without sending both. Drat the pair of them!

wən sɪuən ɹɪtɝnd, wɪð ə wʊɾən tʃɹeɪ hoʊldɪŋ ə sɪlvɝ tipɑɾ ən pɔɹsələn kʌps - ən meɪɡɑnz waɪt-ɡleɪz hʌni dʒɑɹ - ʃi wɑz fɑloʊɾ ɪndə ðə tɛn baɪ ə soʊlʒɝ ɪn pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ɑɹmɝ, ə jʌŋ ʃaɪnɝən wɪð ɪz hɛɹ ʃeɪvd ɔf ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tɑpnɑt. jʌŋ, bʌt nɑt jʌŋ. ɹeɪɡənz dɑɹk tʃik kæɹiɾ ə pʌkɝd waɪt skɑɹ fɹəm ən æɹoʊ, ən ɪz feɪs wɑz hɑɹɾ ɪn ðə weɪ oʊnli ðə feɪs ʌv ə mæn u lɪvd wɪð dɛθ ɛvɹi aʊɝ kəd bi hɑɹd. əz sɪuən dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd tikəps, hi baʊd, wʌn hæn hoʊldɪŋ ə mun-kɹɛstəd hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, ði ʌðɝ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛɾ i hæɾ ɛvɝ mɛɾ əɹ bɪfɔɹ. "ɑnɝ tə sɝv, mʌðɝ," hi sɛd fɔɹməli. "lɔɹd bɹaɪn sɛn mi. hi sɛd tə tɛl jə ðəɾ ɪt simz ðə ɹeɪɾɝz meɪ hæv kɹɔs tə ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ læs naɪt. wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ.

When Siuan returned, with a wooden tray holding a silver teapot and porcelain cups - and Maigan's white-glazed honey jar - she was followed into the tent by a soldier in plate-and-mail armor, a young Shienaran with his hair shaved off except for a topknot. Young, but not young. Ragan's dark cheek carried a puckered white scar from an arrow, and his face was hard in the way only the face of a man who lived with death every hour could be hard. As Siuan distributed teacups, he bowed, one hand holding a moon-crested helmet on his hip, the other on his sword hilt. Nothing in his expression said he had ever met her before. "Honor to serve, Mother," he said formally. "Lord Bryne sent me. He said to tell you that it seems the raiders may have crossed to this side of the river last night. With Aes Sedai.

lɔɹd bɹaɪn ɪz dʌbəlɪŋ ðə pətʃɹoʊlz. hi ædvaɪzɪz ðət sɪstɝz steɪ kloʊs tə ðə kæmp. tə əvɔɪɾ ɪnsəɾənts."

Lord Bryne is doubling the patrols. He advises that sisters stay close to the camp. To avoid incidents."

"meɪ aɪ bi ɪkskjuzd, mʌðɝ?" sɪuən sɛd sʌɾənli, wɪð ðə slaɪtli əbæʃt saʊn ʌv ə wʊmən u faʊn hɝsɛlf wɪð ən ɝdʒənt nid fəɹ ðə dʒeɪks.

"May I be excused, Mother?" Siuan said suddenly, with the slightly abashed sound of a woman who found herself with an urgent need for the Jakes.

"jɛs, jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, əz ɪmpeɪʃənli əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ, ən bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tə dæʃ aʊɾ ə ðə tɛn bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "tɛl lɔɹd bɹaɪn ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡoʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɪʃ, wən ðeɪ wɪʃ." ʃi snæpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kɔl ɪm "ɹeɪɡən," bʌt ðəɾ oʊnli sɝv tə meɪk əɹ sim səvɪɹ. ʃi hoʊpt ɪt dɪd.

"Yes, yes," Egwene said, as impatiently as she could manage, and barely waited for the other woman to dash out of the tent before going on. "Tell Lord Bryne that Aes Sedai go where they wish, when they wish." She snapped her mouth shut before she could call him "Ragan," but that only served to make her seem severe. She hoped it did.

"aɪ wɪl tɛl hɪm, mʌðɝ," hi ɹɪplaɪd, meɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ baʊ.

"I will tell him, Mother," he replied, making another bow.

"hɑɹɾ ən soʊl tə sɝv."

"Heart and soul to serve."

meɪɡɑn smaɪl feɪnli əz i dɪpɑɹɾəd. ʃi dɪpɹəkeɪɾɪd soʊlʒɝz  - wɔɹɾɝz wɝ ɡʊɾ ən nɛsəsɛɹi; soʊlʒɝz meɪd mɛsɪz fəɹ ʌðɝz tə klin ʌp, ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən - bʌt ʃi dɪd feɪvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ðət sim tə ɪndəkeɪɾ ə wɛdʒ bɪtwin ɛɡwin ən ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. əɹ pɝhæps bɛɾɝ tə seɪ ðət ləleɪn feɪvɝd. ɪn ðɪs, meɪɡɑn wɑz ləleɪnz wʊmən tə hɝ toʊneɪlz. maɪɹɛl mɪɹli lʊk pʌzəld. ʃi nu ðəɾ ɛɡwin ɡɑɾ ɑn wɛl wɪð lɔɹd ɡɛɹɪθ. ɛɡwin ɡɑɾ ʌp ən pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti. ən tʊk ə tʌtʃ ə meɪɡɑnz hʌni. hɝ hænz wɝ kwaɪt stɛɾi. ðə boʊts wɝ ɪn pleɪs. ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, lin wəd ɡæðɝ boʊɾ ən ɹaɪd wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə kæmp bɪfɔɹ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du.

Maigan smiled faintly as he departed. She deprecated soldiers  - Warders were good and necessary; soldiers made messes for others to clean up, in her opinion - but she did favor anything that seemed to indicate a wedge between Egwene and Gareth Bryne. Or perhaps better to say that Lelaine favored. In this, Maigan was Lelaine's woman to her toenails. Myrelle merely looked puzzled. She knew that Egwene got on well with Lord Gareth. Egwene got up and poured herself a cup of tea. And took a touch of Maigan's honey. Her hands were quite steady. The boats were in place. In a few hours, Leane would gather Bode and ride well away from the camp before explaining what they were going to do.

lɑɹini mʌs teɪk ðə pʌnɪʃmənt ʃi hæɾ ɝnd, ən boʊd mʌs də wʌt niɾəd duɪŋ. ɛɡwin hæd bɪn jʌŋɡɝ ðən boʊd wən ʃi wɑz sɛt tə hʌn blæk sɪstɝz. ʃaɪnɝənz sɝv ðɛɹ wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ðə blaɪt, hɑɹɾ ən soʊl. ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðoʊz u wəd bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɝv ðə taʊɝ. ə stʃɹɔŋɝ wɛpən əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ðən ɛni sɔɹd, ən noʊ lɛs ʃɑɹp tə ən ənwɛɹi hænd.

Larine must take the punishment she had earned, and Bode must do what needed doing. Egwene had been younger than Bode when she was set to hunt Black sisters. Shienarans served their war against the Shadow in the Blight, heart and soul. Aes Sedai, and those who would become Aes Sedai, served the Tower. A stronger weapon against the Shadow than any sword, and no less sharp to an unwary hand.

wən ɹoʊmændə ɝaɪvd, wɪð θiədʒɹɪn tə hoʊld oʊpən ði ɛntʃɹi flæp fəɹ hɝ, ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd jɛloʊ meɪɾ ə vɛɹi ɪɡzækt kɝtsi, niðɝ ə fɹækʃən mɔɹ nɔɹ lɛs ðən pɹəpɹaɪəɾi ɹikwaɪɝd fɹəm sɪɾɝ tə æmɪɝlɪn. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ðə hɔl, naʊ. ɪf ði æmɪɝlɪn wɑz oʊnli fɝst əmʌŋ ikwəlz ðɛɹ, ʃi wɑz ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪn əɹ oʊn stʌɾi, ivən fəɹ ɹoʊmændə. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ tə kɪs ɛɡwinz ɹɪŋ, ðoʊ. ðəɹ wɝ lɪməts. ʃi aɪd maɪɹɛl ən meɪɡɑn əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv æskɪŋ əm tə liv. əɹ pɝhæps tɛlɪŋ ðɛm. ɪt wɑz ə pɹɪkli pɔɪnt. sɪɾɝz ɪkspɛktəɾ oʊbiɾiəns, bʌt niðɝ wɑz ə hɝ ədʒɑ. ən ðɪs wɑz ði æmɪɝlɪnz stʌɾi.

When Romanda arrived, with Theodrin to hold open the entry flap for her, the gray-haired Yellow made a very exact curtsy, neither a fraction more nor less than propriety required from Sitter to Amyrlin. They were not in the Hall, now. If the Amyrlin was only first among equals there, she was a little more in her own study, even for Romanda. She did not offer to kiss Egwene's ring, though. There were limits. She eyed Myrelle and Maigan as if thinking of asking them to leave. Or perhaps telling them. It was a prickly point. Sitters expected obedience, but neither was of her Ajah. And this was the Amyrlin's study.

ɪn ði ɛnd, ʃi dɪd niðɝ, mɪɹli əlaʊd θiədʒɹɪn tə teɪk əɹ kloʊk, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð bɔɹɾɝz ə jɛloʊ flaʊɝz, ən pɔɹ əɹ ə kʌp ə ti. θiədʒɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi æsk tə də iðɝ, ən ʃi ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə ə kɔɹnɝ, twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl ən əɹ maʊθ sɛt sʌlənli, əz ɹoʊmændə tʊk ði ɛmpti stul.

In the end, she did neither, merely allowed Theodrin to take her cloak, embroidered with borders of yellow flowers, and pour her a cup of tea. Theodrin did not have to be asked to do either, and she retreated to a corner, twitching her shawl and her mouth set sullenly, as Romanda took the empty stool.

dɪspaɪt ðə stulz ənivən lɛɡz, ɹoʊmændə mænədʒ tə meɪk ɪt sim ə siɾ ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, əɹ meɪbi ə θɹoʊn, əz ʃi ədʒʌstəd ðə jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ʃi hæd wɔɹn bɪniθ əɹ kloʊk.

Despite the stool's uneven legs, Romanda managed to make it seem a seat in the Hall of the Tower, or maybe a throne, as she adjusted the yellow-fringed shawl she had worn beneath her cloak.

"ðə tɔks ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ bædli," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət haɪ, mjuzɪkəl vɔɪs. ʃi stɪl meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən. "vɛɹɪlɪn ɪz tʃuɪŋ əɹ lɪps ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. mæɡlə ɪz fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd, tu, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ən ivən sɛɝɔɪjə. wən sɛɝɔɪjə stɑɹts ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɹ tiθ, moʊst sɪstɝz wəd bi ʃaʊɾɪŋ." ɛksɛptɪŋ dʒɑnjə, ɛvɹi sɪɾɝ u hæd hɛld ə tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə taʊɝ dɪvaɪɾəd hæɾ ɪnsɪnjueɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɪndə ðə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz.

"The talks are going badly," she said in that high, musical voice. She still made it sound a proclamation. "Varilin is chewing her lips in frustration. Magla is frustrated, too, for that matter, and even Saroiya. When Saroiya starts grinding her teeth, most sisters would be shouting." Excepting Janya, every Sitter who had held a chair before the Tower divided had insinuated herself into the negotiations.

ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ wɪð wɪmən ðeɪ hæd noʊn ɪn ðə hɔl bæk ðɛn, æftɝ ɔl. bioʊnɪn wɑz nɪɹli ɹədus tə ɹʌnɪŋ ɛɹənz.

They were talking with women they had known in the Hall back then, after all. Beonin was nearly reduced to running errands.

ɹoʊmændə tʌtʃt ðə ti tə hɝ lɪps, ðən hɛl ðə kʌp aʊt tə wʌn saɪɾ ɑn ɪts dɪʃ wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ə wɝd. θiədʒɹɪn dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ tə teɪk ðə kʌp oʊvɝ tə ðə tʃɹeɪ, æɾɪŋ hʌni bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹɪtɝn ðə kʌp tə ðə sɪɾɝ ən hɝsɛlf tə ðə kɔɹnɝ. ɹoʊmændə teɪstəd ðə ti əɡɛn ən nɑɾəd ɪn əpɹuvəl. θiədʒɹɪnz feɪs kʌlɝd. "ðə tɔks wɪl ɡoʊ əz ðeɪ ɡoʊ," ɛɡwin sɛd kɛɹfəli. ɹoʊmændə hæɾ əpoʊzd ɛni sɔɹɾ ə nəɡoʊʃieɪʃənz, spjʊɹiəs əɹ nɑt. ən ʃi nu wʌt wɑz tə hæpən tənaɪt. kipɪŋ ðə hɔl ɪn ðə dɑɹk əbaʊt ðət hæd simd ə nidləs slæp ɪn ðə feɪs. ðə taɪt bʌn ɑn ðə bæk ə ɹoʊmændəz hɛd bɑbd əz ʃi nɑɾəd. "ðeɪ hæv ʃoʊn əs wʌn θɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪleɪɾə woʊn əlaʊ ðə sɪɾɝz spikɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə bʌdʒ ən ɪntʃ. ʃiz dʌɡ ɪndə ðə taʊɝ laɪk ə ɹæɾ ɪn ə wɔl. ði oʊnli weɪ tə flʌʃ əɹ ɪz tə sɛn fɛɹəts ɪn æftɝ hɝ." maɪɹɛl meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ɝnɪŋ ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɡlæns fɹəm meɪɡɑn. ɹoʊmændəz aɪz ɹɪmeɪn stɛɾi ɑn ɛɡwinz.

Romanda touched the tea to her lips, then held the cup out to one side on its dish without saying a word. Theodrin darted from the corner to take the cup over to the tray, adding honey before she returned the cup to the Sitter and herself to the corner. Romanda tasted the tea again and nodded in approval. Theodrin's face colored. "The talks will go as they go," Egwene said carefully. Romanda had opposed any sort of negotiations, spurious or not. And she knew what was to happen tonight. Keeping the Hall in the dark about that had seemed a needless slap in the face. The tight bun on the back of Romanda's head bobbed as she nodded. "They have shown us one thing already. Elaida won't allow the Sitters speaking for her to budge an inch. She is dug into the Tower like a rat in a wall. The only way to flush her is to send ferrets in after her." Myrelle made a sound in her throat, earning a surprised glance from Maigan. Romanda's eyes remained steady on Egwene's.

"ɪleɪɾə wɪl bi ɹimuvd wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli, sɛɾɪŋ əɹ tikʌp daʊn ɑn ɪts dɪʃ. hɝ hæn dɪd nɑt ʃeɪk. wʌt hæd ðə wɪmən lɝnd? haʊ?

"Elaida will be removed one way or another," Egwene said calmly, setting her teacup down on its dish. Her hand did not shake. What had the women learned? How?

ɹoʊmændə ɡɹɪməs feɪnli əɾ əɹ ti əz ɪf æftɝ ɔl ɪt læk səfɪʃən hʌni. əɹ ɪn dɪsəpɔɪnmənt ðəɾ ɛɡwin hæd nɑt sɛd mɔɹ. ðə wʊmən ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ stul wɪð ði ɛɹ ʌv ə sɔɝdzwʊmən sɛɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf fəɹ ənʌðɝ ətæk, bleɪd kʌmɪŋ ʌp. "ðə θɪŋz juv sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə kɪn, mʌðɝ. ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ oʊvɝ ə θaʊzən ə ðɛm ɹæðɝ ðən ə fju dʌzən. ðət səm ɑɹ faɪv əɹ sɪks hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊld." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ oʊvɝ ði ɪmpɔsɪbɪlɪɾi. "haʊ kəɾ ɔl ə ðəɾ əv ɪskeɪp ðə taʊɝ?" ʃi wɑz tʃælənʒɪŋ, nɑɾ æskɪŋ ə kwɛstʃən.

Romanda grimaced faintly at her tea as if after all it lacked sufficient honey. Or in disappointment that Egwene had not said more. The woman shifted on her stool with the air of a swordswoman setting herself for another attack, blade coming up. "The things you've said about the Kin, Mother. That there are over a thousand of them rather than a few dozen. That some are five or six hundred years old." She shook her head over the impossibility. "How could all of that have escaped the Tower?" She was challenging, not asking a question.

"wi oʊnli ɹisənli lɝn haʊ mɛni waɪldɝz ðəɹ ɑɹ əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd dʒɛnli. "ænd wi stɪl ɑɹənt ʃʊɹ haʊ mɛni ðəɹ ɹɪli ɑɹ." ɹoʊmændəz ɡɹɪmɑs wɑz nɑt soʊ smɔl, ðɪs taɪm. ɪt hæd bɪn ðə jɛloʊ ðət fɝs kənfɝm hʌnʒɹədz ə si foʊk waɪldɝz ɪn ɪljən əloʊn. fɝs bloʊ tə ɛɡwin.

"We only recently learned how many wilders there are among the Sea Folk," Egwene replied gently. "And we still aren't sure how many there really are." Romanda's grimace was not so small, this time. It had been the Yellow that first confirmed hundreds of Sea Folk wilders in Illian alone. First blow to Egwene.

wʌn bloʊ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə fɪnɪʃ ɹoʊmændə, ðoʊ. əɹ ivən tə waʊn əɹ vɛɹi bædli. "wi wɪl əv tə hʌn əm daʊn, wʌns əɹ bɪznəs ɪz dʌn hɪɹ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ɡɹɪm toʊnz. "lɛɾɪŋ ə fju dʌzən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ən tɑɹ vəlɑn, dʒʌs tə hɛlp əs tʃɹeɪs ɹʌnəweɪz, wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt wi kænɑɾ əlaʊ ə θaʊzənd waɪldɝz tə ɹɪmeɪn . . . ɔɹɡənaɪzd." ʃi pʊɾ ivən mɔɹ kəntɛmpt ɪndə ðə wɝd, ɪndə ði aɪdiə ʌv waɪldɝz ɔɹɡənaɪzɪŋ, ðən ʃi dɪɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɛst. maɪɹɛl ən meɪɡɑn wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ kloʊsli, lɪsnɪŋ. meɪɡɑn wɑz ivən linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ʃi wɑz soʊ ɪntɛnt. niðɝ nu mɔɹ ðən ðə stɔɹiz ɛɡwin hæd spɹɛd, wɪtʃ ɛvɹiwʌn əsum keɪm θɹu sɪuənz aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz.

One blow was not enough to finish Romanda, though. Or even to wound her very badly. "We will have to hunt them down, once our business is done here," she said in grim tones. "Letting a few dozen remain in Ebou Dar and Tar Valon, just to help us trace runaways, was one thing, but we cannot allow a thousand wilders to remain . . . organized." She put even more contempt into the word, into the idea of wilders organizing, than she did into the rest. Myrelle and Maigan were watching closely, listening. Maigan was even leaning forward, she was so intent. Neither knew more than the stories Egwene had spread, which everyone assumed came through Siuan's eyes-and-ears.

"wɛl oʊvɝ ə θaʊzənd," ɛɡwin kɝɛktəd, "ænd nɑt wʌn ə waɪldɝ. ɔl wɪmən sɛn əweɪ fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju ɹʌnəweɪz u ɪveɪɾɪd kæptʃɝ." ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ itʃ pɔɪn fɝmli, miɾɪŋ ɹoʊmændəz ɡeɪz. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, haʊ dʒju pɹəpoʊz tə hʌn əm daʊn?

"Well over a thousand," Egwene corrected, "and not one a wilder. All women sent away from the Tower, except for a few runaways who evaded capture." She did not raise her voice, but she made each point firmly, meeting Romanda's gaze. "In any case, how do you propose to hunt them down?

ðeɪ ɑɹ spɹɛd θɹu ɛvɹi kʌntʃɹi, ɪn ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑkjəpeɪʃən. ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz ði oʊnli pleɪs ðeɪ ɛvɝ ɡæðɝɾ əɹ mɛɾ ʌðɝ ðən baɪ tʃæns, ən ɔl ðoʊz flɛd wən ðə sintʃæn keɪm. sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ðə kɪn əv əlaʊd ðə taʊɝ tə noʊ oʊnli wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd noʊn. tu θaʊzən jɪɹz, haɪɾɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə waɪt taʊɝz noʊz. ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz əv ɡɹoʊn waɪl ðə taʊɝz nʌmbɝz dwɪndəld.

They are spread through every country, in every sort of occupation. Ebou Dar was the only place they ever gathered or met other than by chance, and all those fled when the Seanchan came. Since the Trolloc Wars, the Kin have allowed the Tower to know only what they wanted known. Two thousand years, hiding under the White Tower's nose. Their numbers have grown while the Tower's numbers dwindled.

haʊ dʒju pɹəpoʊz tə faɪn əm naʊ, əmʌŋ ɔl ðə waɪldɝz aʊt ðəɹ ðət ðə taʊɝ əz ɔlweɪz ɪɡnɔɹd kəz ðeɪ wɝ 'tu oʊld' tə bɪkʌm nɑvəsɪz? kɪnswɪmən doʊn stæn aʊɾ ɪn ɛni weɪ, ɹoʊmændə. ðeɪ juz ðə paʊɝ ɔlmoʊst əz ɔfən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ðeɪ ʃoʊ eɪdʒ laɪk ɛniwʌn ɛls, ɪf mɔɹ sloʊli. ɪf ðeɪ wɑnə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən, wɪl nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ðɛm." ən ðət wɑz sɛvɹəl mɔɹ bloʊz fəɹ ɛɡwin, wɪð nʌn teɪkən. ɹoʊmændə wɔɹ ə feɪnt ʃin ə swɛɾ ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd, ə ʃʊɹ saɪn ə dɛspɝeɪʃən ɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. maɪɹɛl wɑz sɪɾɪŋ vɛɹi stɪl, bʌt meɪɡɑn simd əbaʊt tə fɔl ɔf əɹ stul ɑntu hɝ noʊz noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ stɛɾi ɪt wɑz.

How do you propose to find them now, among all the wilders out there that the Tower has always ignored because they were 'too old' to become novices? Kinswomen don't stand out in any way, Romanda. They use the Power almost as often as Aes Sedai, but they show age like anyone else, if more slowly. If they want to remain hidden, we will never be able to find them." And that was several more blows for Egwene, with none taken. Romanda wore a faint sheen of sweat on her forehead, a sure sign of desperation in an Aes Sedai. Myrelle was sitting very still, but Maigan seemed about to fall off her stool onto her nose no matter how steady it was.

ɹoʊmændə lɪkt əɹ lɪps. "ɪf ðeɪ tʃænəl, ðeɪ wəɾ ətʃiv ðə lʊk. ɪf ðeɪ eɪdʒ, ðeɪ kænɑt bi tʃænəlɪŋ vɛɹi ɔfən ɪf əɾ ɔl. ən niðɝ weɪ kəd ðeɪ laɪv faɪv əɹ sɪks hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz!" noʊ mɔɹ dɪssɪmjəleɪʃən, ɪt simd.

Romanda licked her lips. "If they channel, they would achieve the look. If they age, they cannot be channeling very often if at all. And neither way could they live five or six hundred years!" No more dissimulation, it seemed.

"ðɛɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn ɹil dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə kɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd kwaɪətli. ðə wɝdz stɪl sim laʊd. ivən ɹoʊmændə əpɪɹd tə bi hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ. "ðeɪ lɛf ðə waɪt taʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd swɛɹ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑd." ðɛɹ; ɪt wɑz ɪn ði oʊpən faɪnəli.

"There is only one real difference between Aes Sedai and the Kin," Egwene said quietly. The words still seemed loud. Even Romanda appeared to be holding her breath. "They left the White Tower before they could swear on the Oath Rod." There; it was in the open finally.

ɹoʊmændə dʒɝkt əz ɪf ʃi hæd teɪkən ə mɔɹɾəl bloʊ. "juv nɑt teɪkən ði oʊðz jɛt," ʃi sɛd hɔɹsli. "du jə min tə əbændən ðɛm? tə æsk sɪstɝz tə əbændən ðɛm?" maɪɹɛl əɹ meɪɡɑn ɡæspt.

Romanda jerked as if she had taken a mortal blow. "You've not taken the Oaths yet," she said hoarsely. "Do you mean to abandon them? To ask sisters to abandon them?" Myrelle or Maigan gasped.

pɝhæps boʊθ.

Perhaps both.

"noʊ!" ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ðə θɹi oʊðz ɑɹ wʌt meɪk əs ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əl swɛɹ ɑn ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ əz sun əz ɪts aʊɝz!" dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi mɑdʒəleɪɾɪd əɹ toʊn. bʌt ʃi lin təwɔɹd ði ʌðɝ wʊmən, tu, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ hɝ ɪn, tə ɪnklud hɝ. tə kənvɪns hɝ. ʃi ɔlmoʊst stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hænd. "æz ɪɾ ɪz, sɪstɝz ɹɪtaɪɹ tə spɛn ðɛɹ læs jɪɹz ɪn kwaɪət, ɹoʊmændə. wʊdn ɪt bi bɛɾɝ ɪf ðoʊz wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ læs jɪɹz? ɪf sɪstɝz ɹɪtaɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə kɪn, ðeɪ kəd taɪ ðə kɪn tə ðə taʊɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nid fəɹ ə fjuɾəl hʌnt, ðɛn." ʃi hæd ɡɔn ðɪs fɑɹ; ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡoʊ ðə læst stɛp. "ði oʊθ ɹɑd kən ənbaɪn əz wɛl əz baɪnd." meɪɡɑn θʌddɪd tə ðə kɑɹpəts ɑn əɹ niz ən skɹæmbəld ʌp, bɹʌʃɪŋ əɾ əɹ skɝts əz ɪndɪɡnənli əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn pʊʃt. maɪɹɛlz ɑləv feɪs lʊkt ə lɪɾəl peɪl.

"No!" Egwene said sharply. "The Three Oaths are what make us Aes Sedai, and I will swear on the Oath Rod as soon as it is ours!" Drawing a deep breath, she modulated her tone. But she leaned toward the other woman, too, trying to draw her in, to include her. To convince her. She almost stretched out a hand. "As it is, sisters retire to spend their last years in quiet, Romanda. Wouldn't it be better if those were not their last years? If sisters retired into the Kin, they could tie the Kin to the Tower. There would be no need for a futile hunt, then." She had gone this far; she might as well go the last step. "The Oath Rod can unbind as well as bind." Maigan thudded to the carpets on her knees and scrambled up, brushing at her skirts as indignantly as if she had been pushed. Myrelle's olive face looked a little pale.

muvɪŋ sloʊli, ɹoʊmændə sɛɾ əɹ tikʌp ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl ən stʊd, dʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl ɝaʊn hɝ. ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, ʃi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɛɡwin waɪl θiədʒɹɪn sɛɾəld əɹ jɛloʊ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kloʊk ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, fæsən ðə ɡoʊldən pɪn ən ɝeɪnʒd ðə foʊlz əz kɛɹfəli əz ɛni leɪɾiz meɪd. oʊnli ðən dɪd ɹoʊmændə spik, ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk stoʊn. "wɛn aɪ wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl, aɪ dʒɹimd ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. fɹəm ðə deɪ aɪ ɹitʃt ðə waɪt taʊɝ, aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə lɪv əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ hæv lɪvd əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən əl daɪ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðɪs kænɑt bi əlaʊd!" ʃi tɝn smuðli tə ɡoʊ, bʌt ʃi nɑkt oʊvɝ ðə stul ʃi hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn, əpɛɹənli wɪθaʊt noʊɾɪsɪŋ. θiədʒɹɪn hɝiɾ aʊɾ æftɝ hɝ. wɪð kənsɝn ɑn əɹ feɪs, ɑdli ɪnʌf. "mʌðɝ?" maɪɹɛl dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, fɪŋɡɝz plʌkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dip ɡɹin skɝts. "mʌðɝ, ɑɹ jə ɹɪli sədʒɛstɪŋ . . . ?" ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, əpɛɹənli əneɪbəl tə seɪ ɪt. meɪɡɑn sæɾ ɑn əɹ stul əz ðoʊ fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf nɑt tə lin fɔɹwɝɾ əɡɛn.

Moving slowly, Romanda set her teacup on the edge of the writing table and stood, drawing her shawl around her. Expressionless, she stood staring down at Egwene while Theodrin settled her yellow-embroidered cloak on her shoulders, fastened the golden pin and arranged the folds as carefully as any lady's maid. Only then did Romanda speak, in a voice like stone. "When I was a little girl, I dreamed of becoming Aes Sedai. From the day I reached the White Tower, I tried to live as an Aes Sedai. I have lived as Aes Sedai, and I will die as Aes Sedai. This cannot be allowed!" She turned smoothly to go, but she knocked over the stool she had been sitting on, apparently without noticing. Theodrin hurried out after her. With concern on her face, oddly enough. "Mother?" Myrelle drew a deep breath, fingers plucking at her deep green skirts. "Mother, are you really suggesting . . . ?" She trailed off, apparently unable to say it. Maigan sat on her stool as though forcing herself not to lean forward again.

"aɪ hæv leɪɾ aʊt ðə fæks," ɛɡwin sɛd kɑmli. "ɛni dɪsɪʒən wɪl bi ðə hɔlz. tɛl mi, dɔɾɝ. wəd jə tʃuz tə daɪ, wən jə kəd lɪv ən kəntɪnju tə sɝv ðə taʊɝ?" ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ ən ðə blu ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz, ðən ɹilaɪzd wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn ən snæp bæk tə ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. niðɝ ænsɝd, bʌɾ ɛɡwin kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si ðə θɔts tʃɝnɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ aɪz.

"I have laid out the facts," Egwene said calmly. "Any decision will be the Hall's. Tell me, Daughter. Would you choose to die, when you could live and continue to serve the Tower?" The Green sister and the Blue exchanged glances, then realized what they had done and snapped back to ignoring one another. Neither answered, but Egwene could almost see the thoughts churning behind their eyes.

æftɝ ə fju moʊməns, ʃi ɡɑɾ ʌp ən sɛt ðə stul bæk əpɹaɪt. ivən ðət feɪl tə ɹaʊs əm fɝðɝ ðən pɝfʌŋktɝi əpɑlədʒiz fəɹ meɪkɪŋ əɹ si tə ðət hɝsɛlf. ðən ðeɪ læpst ɪndə saɪlən ɹəflɛkʃən.

After a few moments, she got up and set the stool back upright. Even that failed to rouse them further than perfunctory apologies for making her see to that herself. Then they lapsed into silent reflection.

ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə peɪdʒəz ɪn sɪuənz foʊldɝz - ðə steɪlmeɪɾ ət ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ wɑz dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɑn, ən noʊ wʌn ədmɪɾəd tə ɛni aɪdiə ʌv haʊ ɪt wəɾ ɛnd - bʌt nɑt lɔŋ æftɝ ɹoʊmændəz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, ləleɪn ɝaɪvd.

She tried to return to the pages in Siuan's folders - the stalemate at the Stone of Tear was dragging on, and no one admitted to any idea of how it would end - but not long after Romanda's departure, Lelaine arrived.

ənlaɪk ɹoʊmændə, ðə slɛndɝ blu sɪɾɝ wɑz əloʊn, ən pɔɹɾ əɹ oʊn ti. sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑntu ði ɛmpti stul, ʃi tɔst əɹ fɝ-laɪn kloʊk bæk oʊvɝ boʊθ ʃoʊldɝz ən lɛɾ ɪt hæŋ fɹəm ə sɪlvɝ kloʊk pɪn sɛt wɪð lɑɹdʒ sæfaɪɝz. ʃi wɔɹ əɹ ʃɔl, tu; sɪɾɝz juʒəwəli dɪd. ləleɪn wɑz mɔɹ dɝɛk ðən ɹoʊmændə. əɹ soʊ ɪt maɪɾ əv simd, ɑn ðə sɝfəs. hɝ aɪz hɛld ə ʃɑɹp ɡlɪɾɝ. "kɛɹənz dɛθ pʊɾ ənʌðɝ kɹɪmp ɪn ðə tʃænsəz ə meɪkɪŋ ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv əɡɹimənt wɪð ðə blæk taʊɝ," ʃi mɝmɝɾ oʊvɝ əɹ tikʌp, ɪnheɪlɪŋ ðə fjumz. "æn ðɛɹz pʊɹ lɪw tə dil wɪð. pɝhæps maɪɹɛl wɪl teɪk hɪm. tu ʌv əɹ θɹi bɪlɔŋ tə sʌmwʌn ɛls fɝst. noʊ wʌn ɛls əz ɛvɝ seɪv tu wɔɹɾɝz huz ɛɛs sədaɪ daɪd."

Unlike Romanda, the slender Blue Sitter was alone, and poured her own tea. Settling onto the empty stool, she tossed her fur-lined cloak back over both shoulders and let it hang from a silver cloak pin set with large sapphires. She wore her shawl, too; Sitters usually did. Lelaine was more direct than Romanda. Or so it might have seemed, on the surface. Her eyes held a sharp glitter. "Kairen's death put another crimp in the chances of making any sort of agreement with the Black Tower," she murmured over her teacup, inhaling the fumes. "And there's poor Llyw to deal with. Perhaps Myrelle will take him. Two of her three belonged to someone else first. No one else has ever saved two Warders whose Aes Sedai died."

ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə hɪɹ spɛʃəl ɛmfəsəs ɪn ðæt. maɪɹɛlz feɪs dɛfənətli peɪld.

Egwene was not the only one to hear special emphasis in that. Myrelle's face definitely paled.

ʃi hæd tu sikɹəts tə haɪd, ən wʌn wɑz ðət ʃi hæd fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz. ðə pæsɪŋ ə læn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹənz bɑn fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn tə hɝ hæd bɪn sʌmθɪŋ nɑt dʌn ɪn hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz. tədeɪ, ɪt wɑz lʊkt əpɑn laɪk bɑndɪŋ ə mæn əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl. sʌmθɪŋ nɑt dʌn ɪn ivən mɔɹ hʌnʒɹədz ə jɪɹz. "θɹi ɪz ɪnʌf fəɹ mi," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli. "ɪf jəl ɪkskjuz mi, mʌðɝ?" meɪɡɑn læf sɔfli əz maɪɹɛl lɛf ðə tɛnt wɔkɪŋ fæst. nɑt soʊ fæs ðət ʃi feɪl tə ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ði ɛntʃɹi flæps fɛl, ðoʊ.

She had two secrets to hide, and one was that she had four Warders. The passing of Lan Mandragoran's bond from Moiraine to her had been something not done in hundreds of years. Today, it was looked upon like bonding a man against his will. Something not done in even more hundreds of years. "Three is enough for me," she said breathlessly. "If you will excuse me, Mother?" Maigan laughed softly as Myrelle left the tent walking fast. Not so fast that she failed to embrace saidar before the entry flaps fell, though.

"ʌv kɔɹs," ləleɪn sɛd, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ əmjuz lʊks wɪð ði ʌðɝ blu, "ðeɪ seɪ ʃi mɛɹiz əɹ wɔɹɾɝz. ɔl ə ðɛm. pɝhæps pʊɹ lɪw woʊn də fəɹ ə hʌzbənd."

"Of course," Lelaine said, exchanging amused looks with the other Blue, "they say she marries her Warders. All of them. Perhaps poor Llyw won't do for a husband."

"hi ɪz əz waɪɾ əz ə hɔɹs," meɪɡɑn pʊɾ ɪn. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ əmjuzmən oʊvɝ maɪɹɛlz flaɪt, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mælɪʃəsnəs ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. ʃi wɑz sɪmpli steɪɾɪŋ ə fækt. lɪw wɑz ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ mæn. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ noʊ ə jʌŋ blu hu maɪt teɪk hɪm. ʃi ɪzən ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn mɛn ðət weɪ." ləleɪn nɑɾəd ɪn ə weɪ ðət sɛd ðə jʌŋ blu hæd faʊn əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. "ɡɹinz kən bi vɛɹi ɑd. teɪk ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl. æktʃəli , aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ɪleɪn wəd tʃuz ɡɹin. aɪ hæɾ əɹ mɑɹkt aʊt fəɹ ðə blu. ðə ɡɝl əz ə dɛft fil fəɹ ðə kɝəns ɪn pɑlətɪks. ðoʊ ʃi ɔlsoʊ hæz ə tɛndənsi tə wɑndɝ ɪndə dipɝ wɔɾɝ ðən maɪt bi seɪf. wʊdn jə seɪ soʊ, mʌðɝ?" smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi sɪpt əɾ əɹ ti.

"He is as wide as a horse," Maigan put in. Despite her amusement over Myrelle's flight, there was no maliciousness in her voice. She was simply stating a fact. Llyw was a very large man. "I think I know a young Blue who might take him. She isn't interested in men that way." Lelaine nodded in a way that said the young Blue had found her Warder. "Greens can be very odd. Take Elayne Trakand, for example. Actually, I never thought Elayne would choose Green. I had her marked out for the Blue. The girl has a deft feel for the currents in politics. Though she also has a tendency to wander into deeper water than might be safe. Wouldn't you say so, Mother?" Smiling, she sipped at her tea.

ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk ɹoʊmændəz sʌɾəl filɪŋ-aʊt. ðɪs wɑz slæʃ ən slæʃ, wɪð ðə bleɪɾ əpɪɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ. dɪd ləleɪn noʊ əbaʊt maɪɹɛl ən læn? hæd ʃi sɛn sʌmwʌn tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɪf soʊ, haʊ mʌtʃ hæd ʃi lɝnd? ɛɡwin wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ɹoʊmændə hæɾ ɔlsoʊ fɛlt ɔf-bæləns ən deɪzd. "du jə θɪŋk kɛɹənz mɝɾɝ ɪz ɪnʌf tə stɑp ən əɡɹimənt?" ʃi sɛd. "fɔɹ ɔl ɛniwʌn noʊz, ðɪs kəd bi lɑɡən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fəɹ səm mæd ɹivɛnʒ." waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt hæd ʃi sɛd ðæt? ʃi niɾəd tə pʊɾ ə ɹeɪn ɑn əɹ tʌŋ ən kip əɹ wɪts. "ɔɹ mɔɹ laɪkli, səm pʊɹ ful fɹəm ə fɑɹm ɝaʊn hɪɹ, əɹ wʌn ə ðə bɹɪdʒ taʊnz." ləleɪnz smaɪl dipənd, ən ɪt wɑz mɑkɪŋ, nɑɾ əmjuzd. laɪt, ðə wʊmən hæd nɑt ʃoʊn ðɪs mʌtʃ dɪsɹɪspɛkt ɪn mʌnθs.

This was not at all like Romanda's subtle feeling-out. This was slash and slash, with the blade appearing out of nowhere. Did Lelaine know about Myrelle and Lan? Had she sent someone to Caemlyn, and if so, how much had she learned? Egwene wondered whether Romanda had also felt off-balance and dazed. "Do you think Kairen's murder is enough to stop an agreement?" she said. "For all anyone knows, this could be Logain returning for some mad revenge." Why in the Light had she said that? She needed to put a rein on her tongue and keep her wits. "Or more likely, some poor fool from a farm around here, or one of the bridge towns." Lelaine's smile deepened, and it was mocking, not amused. Light, the woman had not shown this much disrespect in months.

"ɪf lɑɡən wɑntəd ɹivɛnʒ, mʌðɝ, aɪ səspɛkt i wəd bi ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ɹɛdz." dɪspaɪɾ əɹ smaɪl, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz smuð ən lɛvəl. ə dɪstɝbɪŋ kɑntʃɹæst. pɝhæps ðət wɑz əɹ ɪntɛntʃən. "pɝhæps ɪts ə pɪɾi hi ɪzən duɪŋ ðæt. hi maɪt ɹimuv ɪleɪɾə. bʌt ðət wəd bi iziɝ ðən ʃi dɪzɝvz. noʊ, kɛɹən woʊn stɑp ən əɡɹimən ɛni mɔɹ ðən æneɪjə dɪd, bʌt ðə tu kəmbaɪnd wɪl meɪk sɪstɝz wɝi ivən hɑɹɾɝ əbaʊt seɪfɡɑɹdz ən stʃɹɪktʃɝz. wi meɪ nid ðiz mɛn, bʌt wi mʌs bi sɝɾən wəɹ ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. kəmplit kəntʃɹoʊl."

"If Logain wanted revenge, Mother, I suspect he would be in the White Tower trying to kill Reds." Despite her smile, her voice was smooth and level. A disturbing contrast. Perhaps that was her intention. "Perhaps it's a pity he isn't doing that. He might remove Elaida. But that would be easier than she deserves. No, Kairen won't stop an agreement any more than Anaiya did, but the two combined will make sisters worry even harder about safeguards and strictures. We may need these men, but we must be certain we are in control. Complete control."

ɛɡwin nɑɾəd. ə smɔl nɑd. ʃi əɡɹid, bʌt. . . . "ðɛɹ, maɪt bi dɪfəkəltiz bɹɪŋɪŋ əm tə æksɛp ðæt," ʃi sɛd. dɪfəkəltiz. ʃi wɑz dɪspleɪɪŋ ə pɑzəɾɪv tælən fəɹ ʌndɝsteɪtmən tədeɪ.

Egwene nodded. A small nod. She agreed, but. . . . "There, might be difficulties bringing them to accept that," she said. Difficulties. She was displaying a positive talent for understatement today.

"ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn kəd bi mɑɾəfaɪd slaɪtli," meɪɡɑn sɛd. "æz ɪɾ ɪz, jə kən meɪk ðə mæn də əz jə wɪʃ wɪð ə lɪɾəl twikɪŋ, bʌt ðə nid tə twik kəd bi ɹimuv kwaɪɾ izəli."
